GLOSSARY...................................845

ɪt sun bɪkeɪm ɑbviəs, ivən wɪðɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ðət ðə pæɾɝn wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ fɹeɪl. ðə skaɪ dɑɹkənd. əɹ dɛɾ əpɪɹd, stændɪŋ ɪn ɹɪŋz aʊtsaɪd ðə bɔɹɾɝz ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, lʊkɪŋ ɪn. moʊs tʃɹʌbəlɪŋli, tʃɹiz fɛl ɪl, ən noʊ sɔŋ wəd hil ðɛm.

It soon became obvious, even within the stedding, that the Pattern was growing frail. The sky darkened. Our dead appeared, standing in rings outside the borders of the stedding, looking in. Most troublingly, trees fell ill, and no song would heal them.

ɪt wɑz ɪn ðɪs taɪm ə sɑɹoʊz ðəɾ aɪ stɛpt ʌp tə ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp. ət fɝst, aɪ wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən, bʌt maɪ mʌðɝ, koʊvɹəl, dɪmændəɾ aɪ hæv maɪ tʃæns. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌt spɑɹkt əɹ tʃeɪnʒ ə hɑɹt, əz ʃi hɝsɛlf hæɾ ɑɹɡjud kwaɪt dɪsaɪsɪvli fəɹ ði əpoʊzɪŋ saɪd. maɪ hænz ʃʊk. aɪ wəd bi ðə læst spikɝ, ən moʊst sim tə hæv ɔlɹɛɾi meɪɾ ʌp ðɛɹ maɪnz tə oʊpən ðə bʊk ə tʃɹænzleɪʃən. ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝd mi ən æftɝθɑt.

It was in this time of sorrows that I stepped up to the Great Stump. At first, I was forbidden, but my mother, Covril, demanded I have my chance. I do not know what sparked her change of heart, as she herself had argued quite decisively for the opposing side. My hands shook. I would be the last speaker, and most seemed to have already made up their minds to open the Book of Translation. They considered me an afterthought.

ən aɪ nu ðəɾ ənlɛs aɪ spoʊk tʃɹu, hjumænɪɾi wəd bi lɛft əloʊn tə feɪs ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðət moʊmənt, maɪ nɝvəsnəs flɛd. aɪ fɛlt oʊnli ə stɪlnəs, ə kɑm sɛns ə pɝpəs. aɪ oʊpən maɪ maʊθ, ən aɪ bɪɡæn tə spik.

And I knew that unless I spoke true, humanity would be left alone to face the Shadow. In that moment, my nervousness fled. I felt only a stillness, a calm sense of purpose. I opened my mouth, and I began to speak.

 - fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, baɪ lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, ʌv stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ 
 - from The Dragon Reborn, by Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, of Stedding Shangtai 
pɹoʊlɑɡ dɪstɪŋkʃənz



PROLOGUE Distinctions

mændɑɹbz hʊvz biɾ ə fəmɪljɝ ɹɪðəm ɑn bɹoʊkən ɡɹaʊn əz læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən ɹoʊd təwɔɹɾ ɪz dɛθ. ðə dʒɹaɪ ɛɹ meɪɾ ɪz θɹoʊt ɹʌf ən ði ɝθ wɑz spɹɪŋkəld waɪt wɪð kɹɪstəlz ə sɔl ðət pɹɪsɪpɪteɪɾɪd fɹəm bɪloʊ. dɪstən ɹɛd ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃənz lum tə ðə nɔɹθ, wɛɹ sɪknəs steɪn ðɛm. blaɪt mɑɹks, ə kɹipɪŋ dɑɹk laɪkən.

Mandarb's hooves beat a familiar rhythm on broken ground as Lan Mandragoran rode toward his death. The dry air made his throat rough and the earth was sprinkled white with crystals of salt that precipitated from below. Distant red rock formations loomed to the north, where sickness stained them. Blight marks, a creeping dark lichen.

hi kəntɪnjud ɹaɪɾɪŋ ist, pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə blaɪt. ðɪs wɑz stɪl sɑldɑiə, wɛɹ ɪz waɪf hæd dəpɑzɪɾɪd hɪm, oʊnli nɛɹoʊli kipɪŋ əɹ pɹɑməs tə teɪk ɪm tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ɪt hæd stʃɹɛtʃt bɪfɔɹ ɪm fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, ðɪs ɹoʊd. hid tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ɪt twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, əɡɹiɪŋ tə fɑloʊ mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌt hiɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn i wəd ɹɪtɝn. ðɪs wɑz wʌɾ ɪt mɛn tə bɛɹ ðə neɪm ə hɪz fɑðɝz, ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, ən ðə hædɔɹi ɑn ɪz hɛd.

He continued riding east, parallel to the Blight. This was still Saldaea, where his wife had deposited him, only narrowly keeping her promise to take him to the Borderlands. It had stretched before him for a long time, this road. He'd turned away from it twenty years ago, agreeing to follow Moiraine, but he'd always known he would return. This was what it meant to bear the name of his fathers, the sword on his hip, and the hadori on his head.

ðɪs ɹɑki sɛkʃən ə nɔɹðɝn sɑldɑiə wɑz noʊn əz ðə pɹɔskə flæts. ɪt wɑz ə ɡɹɪm pleɪs tə ɹaɪd; nɑɾ ə plænt ɡɹu ɑn ɪt. ðə wɪn blu fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, kæɹiɪŋ wɪð ɪɾ ə faʊl stɛntʃ. laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ə dip, swɛltɝɪŋ maɪɹ bloʊɾɪd wɪð kɔɹpsəz. ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd stɔɹm dɑɹk, bɹuɾɪŋ.

This rocky section of northern Saldaea was known as the Proska Flats. It was a grim place to ride; not a plant grew on it. The wind blew from the north, carrying with it a foul stench. Like that of a deep, sweltering mire bloated with corpses. The sky overhead stormed dark, brooding.

ðət wʊmən, læn θɔt, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. haʊ kwɪkli nɪneɪiv hæd lɝn tə tɔk, ən θɪŋk, laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə hɪz dɛθ dɪdn peɪn hɪm, bʌt noʊɪŋ ʃi fɪɹd fəɹ ɪm . . . ðət dɪd hɝt. vɛɹi bædli.

That woman, Lan thought, shaking his head. How quickly Nynaeve had learned to talk, and think, like an Aes Sedai. Riding to his death didn't pain him, but knowing she feared for him . . . that did hurt. Very badly.

hi hædn sin ənʌðɝ pɝsən ɪn deɪz. ðə sɑldəiənz hæd fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz tə ðə saʊθ, bʌt ðə læn hɪɹ wɑz skɑɹd wɪð bɹoʊkən ɹeɪvinz ðət meɪɾ ɪt dɪfəkəl fəɹ tʃɹɑləks tə əsɔlt; ðeɪ pɹəfɝɾ ətækɪŋ nɪɹ mɛɹədɑn.

He hadn't seen another person in days. The Saldaeans had fortifications to the south, but the land here was scarred with broken ravines that made it difficult for Trollocs to assault; they preferred attacking near Maradon.

ðət wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə ɹɪlæks, haʊɛvɝ. wʌn ʃəd nɛvɝ ɹɪlæks, ðɪs kloʊs tə ðə blaɪt. hi noʊɾəd ə hɪltɑp; ðət wəd bi ə ɡʊd pleɪs fəɹ ə skaʊts poʊst. hi meɪd sɝɾən tə wɑtʃ ɪt fəɹ ɛni saɪn ə muvmənt. hi ɹoʊɾ ɝaʊn ə dɪpɹɛʃən ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ɪt hɛld weɪɾɪŋ æm-bʊʃɝz. hi kɛpt ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz baʊ. wʌns i tʃɹævəld ə lɪɾəl fɑɹðɝ istwɝd, hid kʌt daʊn ɪndə sɑldɑiə ən kɹɔs kændɝ ɑn ɪts ɡʊd ɹoʊdweɪz. ðən -  səm ɡɹævəl ɹoʊl daʊn ə hɪlsaɪd nɪɹbaɪ.

That was no reason to relax, however. One should never relax, this close to the Blight. He noted a hilltop; that would be a good place for a scout's post. He made certain to watch it for any sign of movement. He rode around a depression in the ground, just in case it held waiting am-bushers. He kept his hand on his bow. Once he traveled a little farther eastward, he'd cut down into Saldaea and cross Kandor on its good roadways. Then -  Some gravel rolled down a hillside nearby.

læn kɛɹfəli slɪɾ ən æɹoʊ fɹəm ðə kwɪvɝ taɪd tə mændɑɹbz sæɾəl. wɛɹ hæd ðə saʊn kʌm fɹʌm? tə ðə ɹaɪt, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd. saʊθwɝd. ðə hɪlsaɪd ðɛɹ; sʌmwʌn wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ fɹəm bɪhaɪn ɪt.

Lan carefully slid an arrow from the quiver tied to Mandarb's saddle. Where had the sound come from? To the right, he decided. Southward. The hillside there; someone was approaching from behind it.

læn dɪd nɑt stɑp mændɑɹb. ɪf ðə hʊfbits tʃeɪnʒd, ɪt wəd ɡɪv wɔɹnɪŋ. hi kwaɪətli ɹeɪz ðə baʊ, filɪŋ ðə swɛɾ ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz fɔn-haɪd ɡlʌvz. hi nɑk ði æɹoʊ ən pʊl kɛɹfəli, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪt tə hɪz tʃik, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ɪts sɛnt. ɡus fɛðɝz, ɹɛzən.

Lan did not stop Mandarb. If the hoofbeats changed, it would give warning. He quietly raised the bow, feeling the sweat of his fingers inside his fawn-hide gloves. He nocked the arrow and pulled carefully, raising it to his cheek, breathing in its scent. Goose feathers, resin.

ə fɪɡjɝ wɔkt ɝaʊn ðə sʌðɝn hɪlsaɪd. ðə mæn fɹoʊz, ən oʊld, ʃæɡi-meɪn pækhɔɹs wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ən kəntɪnjuɪŋ ɑn əhɛd. ɪt stɑpt oʊnli wən ðə ɹoʊp əɾ ɪts nɛk ɡɹu tɔt.

A figure walked around the southern hillside. The man froze, an old, shaggy-maned packhorse walking around beside him and continuing on ahead. It stopped only when the rope at its neck grew taut.

ðə mæn wɔɹ ə leɪs tæn ʃɝɾ ən dʌsti bɹitʃɪz. hi hæɾ ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst, ən ɪz ɑɹmz wɝ θɪk ən stʃɹɔŋ, bʌɾ i dɪdn lʊk θɹɛɾənɪŋ. ɪn fækt, hi sim feɪnli fəmɪljɝ.

The man wore a laced tan shirt and dusty breeches. He had a sword at his waist, and his arms were thick and strong, but he didn't look threatening. In fact, he seemed faintly familiar.

"lɔɹd mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən!" ðə mæn sɛd, heɪsənɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs æftɝ. "aɪv faʊn jə ət læst. aɪ əsum jud bi tʃɹævlɪŋ ðə kɹ-mɛɹ ɹoʊd!"

"Lord Mandragoran!" the man said, hastening forward, pulling his horse after. "I've found you at last. I assumed you'd be traveling the Kre-mer Road!"

læn loʊɝɾ ɪz baʊ ən stɑp mændɑɹb. "du aɪ noʊ ju?"

Lan lowered his bow and stopped Mandarb. "Do I know you?"

"aɪ bɹɔt səplaɪz, maɪ lɔɹd!" ðə mæn hæd blæk hɛɹ ən tæn skɪn. bɔɹɾɝləndɝ stɑk, pɹɑbli. hi kəntɪnjud fɔɹwɝd, oʊvɝiɡɝ, jæŋkɪŋ ɑn ði oʊvɝloʊɾɪd pækhɔɹsəz ɹoʊp wɪð ə θɪk- fɪŋɡɝd hænd. "aɪ fɪɡjɝd ðət jə wʊdn əv ɪnʌf fud. tɛns - fɔɹ ə ðɛm, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs - səm wɔɾɝ tu. fid fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz. ən - "

"I brought supplies, my Lord!" The man had black hair and tanned skin. Borderlander stock, probably. He continued forward, overeager, yanking on the overloaded packhorse's rope with a thick- fingered hand. "I figured that you wouldn't have enough food. Tents - four of them, just in case - some water too. Feed for the horses. And - "

"hu ɑɹ ju?" læn bɑɹkt. "æn haʊ dʒju noʊ hu aɪ æm?"

"Who are you?" Lan barked. "And how do you know who I am?"

ðə mæn dʒɹu ʌp ʃɑɹpli. "aɪm bʌlən, maɪ lɔɹd. fɹəm kændɝ?"

The man drew up sharply. "I'm Bulen, my Lord. From Kandor?"

fɹəm kændɝ . . . læn ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə ɡæŋli jʌŋ mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪ. wɪð sɝpɹaɪz, hi sɔ ðə ɹɪzɛmbləns. "bʌlən? ðət wɑz twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, mæn!"

From Kandor . . . Lan remembered a gangly young messenger boy. With surprise, he saw the resemblance. "Bulen? That was twenty years ago, man!"

"aɪ noʊ, lɔɹd mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən. bʌt wən wɝd spɹɛɾ ɪn ðə pæləs ðət ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn wɑz ɹeɪzd, aɪ nu wʌɾ aɪ hæd tə du. aɪv lɝn ðə sɔɹd wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪv kʌm tə ɹaɪd wɪð jə ænd  - "

"I know, Lord Mandragoran. But when word spread in the palace that the Golden Crane was raised, I knew what I had to do. I've learned the sword well, my Lord. I've come to ride with you and  - "

"ðə wɝɾ ə maɪ tʃɹævəl əz spɹɛd tə ɛɛzdeɪʃɝ?"

"The word of my travel has spread to Aesdaishar?"

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪlnineɪiv, ʃi keɪm tə ʌs, jə si. toʊld əs wʌt jud dʌn. ʌðɝz ɑɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ lɛft fɝst. nu jud nid səplaɪz."

"Yes, my Lord. El'Nynaeve, she came to us, you see. Told us what you'd done. Others are gathering, but I left first. Knew you'd need supplies."

bɝn ðət wʊmən, læn θɔt. ən ʃid meɪɾ ɪm swɛɹ ðəɾ i wəɾ æksɛp ðoʊz u wɪʃt tə ɹaɪd wɪð hɪm! wɛl, ɪf ʃi kəd pleɪ ɡeɪmz wɪð ðə tʃɹuθ, ðən soʊ kəd hi. læn hæd sɛd hid teɪk ɛniwʌn u wɪʃt tə ɹaɪd wɪð hɪm. ðɪs mæn wɑz nɑt maʊntəd. ðɛɹfɔɹ, læn kəd ɹəfjuz hɪm. ə pɛɾi dɪstɪŋkʃən, bʌt twɛnti jɪɹz wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd tɔɾ ɪm ə fju θɪŋz əbaʊt haʊ tə wɑtʃ wʌnz wɝdz.

Burn that woman, Lan thought. And she'd made him swear that he would accept those who wished to ride with him! Well, if she could play games with the truth, then so could he. Lan had said he'd take anyone who wished to ride with him. This man was not mounted. Therefore, Lan could refuse him. A petty distinction, but twenty years with Aes Sedai had taught him a few things about how to watch one's words.

"ɡoʊ bæk tə ɛɛzdeɪʃɝ," læn sɛd. "tɛl əm ðət maɪ waɪf wɑz ɹɔŋ, ən aɪ hæv nɑt ɹeɪz ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn."

"Go back to Aesdaishar," Lan said. "Tell them that my wife was wrong, and I have not raised the Golden Crane."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"aɪ doʊnt nid ju, sʌn. əweɪ wɪð ju." lænz hilz nʌdʒ mændɑɹb ɪndə ə wɔk, ən i pæs ðə mæn stændɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. fəɹ ə fju moʊməns, læn θɔt ðəɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝ wəd bi oʊbeɪd, ðoʊ ði ɪveɪʒən ə hɪz oʊθ pɹɪkt əɾ ɪz kɑnʃəns.

"I don't need you, son. Away with you." Lan's heels nudged Mandarb into a walk, and he passed the man standing on the road. For a few moments, Lan thought that his order would be obeyed, though the evasion of his oath pricked at his conscience.

"maɪ fɑðɝ wɑz mɔlkɪɹi," bʌlən sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

"My father was Malkieri," Bulen said from behind.

læn kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn.

Lan continued on.

"hi daɪd wən aɪ wɑz faɪv," bʌlən kɔld. "hi mɛɹiɾ ə kændɔɹi wʊmən. ðeɪ boʊθ fɛl tə bændəts. aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ mʌtʃ ə ðɛm. oʊnli sʌmθɪŋ maɪ fɑðɝ toʊl mi: ðət sʌmdeɪ, wi wəd faɪt fəɹ ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn. ɔl aɪ hæv ə hɪm ɪz ðɪs."

"He died when I was five," Bulen called. "He married a Kandori woman. They both fell to bandits. I don't remember much of them. Only something my father told me: that someday, we would fight for the Golden Crane. All I have of him is this."

læn kʊdn hɛlp bʌt lʊk bæk əz mændɑɹb kəntɪnjud tə wɔk əweɪ. bʌlən hɛld ʌp ə θɪn stʃɹæp ə lɛðɝ, ðə hædɔɹi, wɔɹn ɑn ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə mɔlkɪɹi swɔɹn tə faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ.

Lan couldn't help but look back as Mandarb continued to walk away. Bulen held up a thin strap of leather, the hadori, worn on the head of a Malkieri sworn to fight the Shadow.

"aɪ wəd wɛɹ ðə hædɔɹi ʌv maɪ fɑðɝ," bʌlən kɔld, vɔɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊbɑdi tə æsk ɪf aɪ meɪ. ðəɾ ɪz ðə tʃɹədɪʃən, ɪz ɪt nɑt? sʌmwʌn əz tə ɡɪmi ðə ɹaɪt tə dɑn ɪt. wɛl, aɪ wəd faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ ɔl maɪ deɪz." hi lʊk daʊn ət ðə hædɔɹi, ðən bæk ʌp əɡɛn ən jɛld, "aɪ wəd stæn əɡɛns ðə dɑɹknəs, ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən! wɪl jə tɛl mi aɪ kænɑt?"

"I would wear the hadori of my father," Bulen called, voice growing louder. "But I have nobody to ask if I may. That is the tradition, is it not? Someone has to give me the right to don it. Well, I would fight the Shadow all my days." He looked down at the hadori, then back up again and yelled, "I would stand against the darkness, al'Lan Mandragoran! Will you tell me I cannot?"

"ɡoʊ tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," læn kɔl tə hɪm. "ɔɹ tə jəɹ kwinz ɑɹmi. iðɝ ə ðɛm wɪl teɪk ju."

"Go to the Dragon Reborn," Lan called to him. "Or to your queen's army. Either of them will take you."

"æn ju? jəl ɹaɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz wɪθaʊt səplaɪz?"

"And you? You will ride all the way to the Seven Towers without supplies?"

"aɪl fɔɹɪdʒ."

"I'll forage."

"pɑɹɾən mi, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌɾ əv jə sin ðə læn ðiz deɪz? ðə blaɪt kɹips fɑɹðɝ ən fɑɹðɝ saʊθ. nʌθɪŋ ɡɹoʊz, ivən ɪn wʌns-fɝɾəl lænz. ɡeɪm ɪz skɛɹs."

"Pardon me, my Lord, but have you seen the land these days? The Blight creeps farther and farther south. Nothing grows, even in once-fertile lands. Game is scarce."

læn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi ɹeɪn mændɑɹb ɪn.

Lan hesitated. He reined Mandarb in.

"ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz əɡoʊ," bʌlən kɔld, wɔkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, hɪz pækhɔɹs wɔkɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. "aɪ hɑɹdli nu hu jə wɝ, ðoʊ aɪ noʊ jə lɔst sʌmwʌn dɪɹ tə jə əmʌŋ ʌs. aɪv spɛn jɪɹz kɝsɪŋ maɪsɛlf fəɹ nɑt sɝvɪŋ jə bɛɾɝ. aɪ swɔɹ ðəɾ aɪ wəd stænd wɪð jə sʌmdeɪ." hi wɔkt ʌp bɪsaɪd læn. "aɪ æsk jə kəz aɪ hæv noʊ fɑðɝ. meɪ aɪ wɛɹ ðə hædɔɹi ən faɪɾ ət jəɹ saɪd, ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən? maɪ kɪŋ?"

"All those years ago," Bulen called, walking forward, his packhorse walking behind him. "I hardly knew who you were, though I know you lost someone dear to you among us. I've spent years cursing myself for not serving you better. I swore that I would stand with you someday." He walked up beside Lan. "I ask you because I have no father. May I wear the hadori and fight at your side, al'Lan Mandragoran? My King?"

læn bɹiðd aʊt sloʊli, stɪlɪŋ ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz. nɪneɪiv, wən nɛkst aɪ si jə . . . bʌɾ i wəd nɑt si hɝ əɡɛn. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə dwɛl əpɑn ðæt.

Lan breathed out slowly, stilling his emotions. Nynaeve, when next I see you . . . But he would not see her again. He tried not to dwell upon that.

hi hæd meɪɾ ən oʊθ. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪɡɡəld ɝaʊn ðɛɹ pɹɑməsəz, bʌt dɪd ðət ɡɪv ɪm ðə seɪm ɹaɪt? noʊ. ə mæn wɑz ɪz ɑnɝ. hi kəd nɑt dɪnaɪ bʌlən.

He had made an oath. Aes Sedai wiggled around their promises, but did that give him the same right? No. A man was his honor. He could not deny Bulen.

"wi ɹaɪɾ ənɑnəməsli," læn sɛd. "wi də nɑt ɹeɪz ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn. jə tɛl noʊbɑdi hu aɪ æm."

"We ride anonymously," Lan said. "We do not raise the Golden Crane. You tell nobody who I am."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," bʌlən sɛd.

"Yes, my Lord," Bulen said.

"ðɛn wɛɹ ðət hædɔɹi wɪð pɹaɪd," læn sɛd. "tu fju kip tə ði oʊld weɪz. ən jɛs, jə meɪ dʒɔɪn mi."

"Then wear that hadori with pride," Lan said. "Too few keep to the old ways. And yes, you may join me."

læn nʌdʒ mændɑɹb ɪndə moʊʃən, bʌlən fɑloʊɪŋ ɑn fʊt. ən ðə wʌn bɪkeɪm tu.

Lan nudged Mandarb into motion, Bulen following on foot. And the one became two.

pɛɹɪn slæmd ɪz hæmɝ əɡɛns ðə ɹɛd-hɑt lɛŋθ ʌv aɪɝn. spɑɹks spɹeɪɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ laɪk ɪnkəndɛsən ɪnsɛks. swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz feɪs.

Perrin slammed his hammer against the red-hot length of iron. Sparks sprayed into the air like incandescent insects. Sweat beaded on his face.

səm pipəl faʊn ðə klæŋ ə mɛɾəl əɡɛns mɛɾəl ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ. nɑt pɛɹɪn. ðət saʊnd wɑz suðɪŋ.

Some people found the clang of metal against metal grating. Not Perrin. That sound was soothing.

hi ɹeɪz ðə hæmɝ ən slæmd ɪt daʊn.

He raised the hammer and slammed it down.

spɑɹks. flaɪɪŋ tʃɪps ə laɪt ðət baʊnst ɔf ɪz lɛðɝ vɛst ən ɪz eɪpɹən. wɪð itʃ stʃɹaɪk, ðə wɔlz ə ðə ɹum - stɝɾi lɛðɝlif wʊd -  fʌzd, ɹɪspɑndɪŋ tə ðə bits ə mɛɾəl ɑn mɛɾəl. hi wɑz dʒɹimɪŋ, ðoʊ hi wɑzn ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. hi nu ðɪs, ðoʊ hi dɪdnt noʊ haʊ hi nu.

Sparks. Flying chips of light that bounced off his leather vest and his apron. With each strike, the walls of the room - sturdy leatherleaf wood -  fuzzed, responding to the beats of metal on metal. He was dreaming, though he wasn't in the wolf dream. He knew this, though he didn't know how he knew.

ðə wɪndoʊz wɝ dɑɹk; ði oʊnli laɪt wɑz ðəɾ ə ðə dip ɹɛd faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt. tu bɑɹz ʌv aɪɝn sɪmɝɾ ɪn ðə koʊlz, weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn ət ðə fɔɹdʒ. pɛɹɪn slæm ðə hæmɝ daʊn əɡɛn.

The windows were dark; the only light was that of the deep red fire burning on his right. Two bars of iron simmered in the coals, waiting their turn at the forge. Perrin slammed the hammer down again.

ðɪs wɑz pis. ðɪs wɑz hoʊm.

This was peace. This was home.

hi wɑz meɪkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. soʊ vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ɪt wɑz ə pis ə sʌmθɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ. ðə fɝst stɛp tə kɹieɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ wɑz tə fɪɡjɝ aʊɾ ɪts pɑɹts. mæstɝ luhən hæd tɔt pɛɹɪn ðəɾ ɑn ɪz fɝs deɪ ət ðə fɔɹdʒ. jə kʊdn meɪk ə speɪd wɪθaʊɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ haʊ ðə hændəl fɪt tə ðə bleɪd. jə kʊdn meɪk ə hɪnʒ wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ haʊ ðə tu livz muvd wɪð ðə pɪn. jə kʊdn ivən meɪk ə neɪl wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ ɪts pɑɹts: hɛd, ʃæft, pɔɪnt.

He was making something important. So very important. It was a piece of something larger. The first step to creating something was to figure out its parts. Master Luhhan had taught Perrin that on his first day at the forge. You couldn't make a spade without understanding how the handle fit to the blade. You couldn't make a hinge without knowing how the two leaves moved with the pin. You couldn't even make a nail without knowing its parts: head, shaft, point.

ʌndɝstæn ðə pisəz, pɛɹɪn.

Understand the pieces, Perrin.

ə wʊlf leɪ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum. ɪt wɑz lɑɹdʒ ən ɡɹɪzəld, fɝ ðə kʌlɝ ʌv ə peɪl ɡɹeɪ ɹɪvɝ stoʊn, ən skɑɹd fɹəm ə laɪftaɪm ə bæɾəlz ən hʌns. ðə wʊlf leɪɾ ɪts hɛɾ ɑn ɪts pɔz, wɑtʃɪŋ pɛɹɪn. ðət wɑz nætʃɹəl. ʌv kɔɹs ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊlf ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. waɪ wʊdn ðəɹ bi? ɪt wɑz hɑpɝ.

A wolf lay in the corner of the room. It was large and grizzled, fur the color of a pale gray river stone, and scarred from a lifetime of battles and hunts. The wolf laid its head on its paws, watching Perrin. That was natural. Of course there was a wolf in the corner. Why wouldn't there be? It was Hopper.

pɛɹɪn wɝkt, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə dip, bɝnɪŋ hiɾ ə ðə fɔɹdʒ, ðə fil ə ðə swɛt tʃɹeɪlɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɑɹmz, ðə sɛn ə ðə faɪɝ. hi ʃeɪp ðə lɛŋθ ʌv aɪɝn, wʌn bloʊ fəɹ ɛvɹi sɛkən biɾ ə hɪz hɑɹt.

Perrin worked, enjoying the deep, burning heat of the forge, the feel of the sweat trailing down his arms, the scent of the fire. He shaped the length of iron, one blow for every second beat of his heart.

ðə mɛɾəl nɛvɝ ɡɹu kul, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd ɹɪteɪn ɪts mæliəbəl ɹɛd-jɛloʊ.

The metal never grew cool, but instead retained its malleable red-yellow.

wʌɾ æm aɪ meɪkɪŋ? pɛɹɪn pɪkt ʌp ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ aɪɝn wɪð ɪz tɑŋz. ði ɛɹ wɔɹpt ɝaʊn ɪt.

What am I making? Perrin picked up the length of glowing iron with his tongs. The air warped around it.

paʊnd, paʊnd, paʊnd, hɑpɝ sɛnt, kəmjunəkeɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪmədʒəz ən sɛns. laɪk ə pʌp dʒʌmpɪŋ ət bʌɾɝflaɪz.

Pound, pound, pound, Hopper sent, communicating in images and scents. Like a pup jumping at butterflies.

hɑpɝ dɪdn si ðə pɔɪn ə ɹiʃeɪpɪŋ mɛɾəl, ən faʊn ɪɾ əmjuzɪŋ ðət mɛn dɪd sətʃ θɪŋz. tə ə wʊlf, ə θɪŋ wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. waɪ ɡoʊ θɹu soʊ mʌtʃ ɛfɝt tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪɾ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ɛls?

Hopper didn't see the point of reshaping metal, and found it amusing that men did such things. To a wolf, a thing was what it was. Why go through so much effort to change it into something else?

pɛɹɪn sɛt ðə lɛŋθ ʌv aɪɝn əsaɪd. ɪt kuld ɪmiɾiətli, feɪɾɪŋ fɹəm jɛloʊ, tə ɔɹənʒ, tə kɹɪmzən, tə ə dʌl blæk. pɛɹɪn hæd paʊndɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ə mɪsʃeɪpən nʌɡɪt, pɝhæps ðə saɪz ə tu fɪsts.

Perrin set the length of iron aside. It cooled immediately, fading from yellow, to orange, to crimson, to a dull black. Perrin had pounded it into a misshapen nugget, perhaps the size of two fists.

mæstɝ luhən wəd bi əʃeɪm tə si sətʃ ʃɑɾi wɝk. pɛɹɪn niɾəd tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌɾ i wɑz meɪkɪŋ sun, bɪfɔɹ ɪz mæstɝ ɹɪtɝnd.

Master Luhhan would be ashamed to see such shoddy work. Perrin needed to discover what he was making soon, before his master returned.

noʊ. ðət wɑz ɹɔŋ. ðə dʒɹim ʃʊk, ən ðə wɔlz ɡɹu mɪsti.

No. That was wrong. The dream shook, and the walls grew misty.

aɪm nɑɾ ən əpɹɛntəs. pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ə θɪk-ɡlʌv hæn tə hɪz hɛd. aɪm nɑɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ɪm ə mæn, ə mɛɹid mæn.

I'm not an apprentice. Perrin raised a thick-gloved hand to his head. I'm not in the Two Rivers any longer. I'm a man, a married man.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹæb ðə lʌmp ʌv ənʃeɪpt aɪɝn wɪð ɪz tɑŋz, θɹʌstɪŋ ɪt daʊn ɑn ði ænvəl. ɪt flɛɹd tə laɪf wɪð hit. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz stɪl ɹɔŋ. pɛɹɪn smæʃt ɪz hæmɝ daʊn. ɪt ʃəɾ ɔl bi bɛɾɝ naʊ! bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzənt. ɪt simz wɝs sʌmhaʊ.

Perrin grabbed the lump of unshaped iron with his tongs, thrusting it down on the anvil. It flared to life with heat. Everything is still wrong. Perrin smashed his hammer down. It should all be better now! But it isn't. It seems worse somehow.

hi kəntɪnjud paʊndɪŋ. hi heɪɾəd ðoʊz ɹumɝz ðət ðə mɛn ɪn kæmp wɪspɝɾ əbaʊt hɪm. pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn sɪk ən bɹəleɪn hæd kɛɹd fəɹ hɪm. ðət wɑz ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. bʌt stɪl ðoʊz wɪspɝz kəntɪnjud.

He continued pounding. He hated those rumors that the men in camp whispered about him. Perrin had been sick and Berelain had cared for him. That was the end of it. But still those whispers continued.

hi slæmd ɪz hæmɝ daʊn oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ. spɑɹks flu ɪn ði ɛɹ laɪk splæʃəz ʌv wɔɾɝ, fɑɹ tu mɛni tə kʌm fɹəm wʌn lɛŋθ ʌv aɪɝn. hi ɡeɪv wʌn faɪnəl stʃɹaɪk, ðən bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt.

He slammed his hammer down over and over. Sparks flew in the air like splashes of water, far too many to come from one length of iron. He gave one final strike, then breathed in and out.

ðə lʌmp hædn tʃeɪnʒd. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ən ɡɹæb ðə tɑŋz, sɛɾɪŋ ðə lʌmp əsaɪɾ ən teɪkɪŋ ə fɹɛʃ bɑɹ fɹəm ðə koʊlz. hi hæd tə fɪnɪʃ ðɪs pis. ɪt wɑz soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. bʌt wʌt wɑz i meɪkɪŋ?

The lump hadn't changed. Perrin growled and grabbed the tongs, setting the lump aside and taking a fresh bar from the coals. He had to finish this piece. It was so important. But what was he making?

hi stɑɹɾəd paʊndɪŋ. aɪ nid tə spɛn taɪm wɪð feɪl, tə fɪɡjɝ θɪŋz aʊt, ɹimuv ði ɔkwɝdnəs bɪtwin ʌs. bʌt ðɛɹz noʊ taɪm! ðoʊz laɪt-blaɪndɪd fulz ɝaʊn ɪm kʊdn teɪk kɛɹ ə ðɛmsɛlvz. noʊbɑdi ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɛvɝ niɾəd ə lɔɹd bɪfɔɹ.

He started pounding. I need to spend time with Faile, to figure things out, remove the awkwardness between us. But there's no time! Those Light-blinded fools around him couldn't take care of themselves. Nobody in the Two Rivers ever needed a lord before.

hi wɝk fəɹ ə taɪm, ðən hɛld ʌp ðə sɛkən tʃʌŋk ʌv aɪɝn. ɪt kuld, tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ə mɪsʃeɪpən, flæɾənd lɛŋθ əbaʊɾ əz lɔŋ əz ɪz fɔɹɑɹm. ənʌðɝ ʃɑɾi pis. hi sɛɾ ɪɾ əsaɪd.

He worked for a time, then held up the second chunk of iron. It cooled, turning into a misshapen, flattened length about as long as his forearm. Another shoddy piece. He set it aside.

ɪf jə ɑɹ ənhæpi, hɑpɝ sɛnt, teɪk jəɹ ʃi ən liv. ɪf jə də nɑt wɪʃ tə lid ðə pæk, ənʌðɝ wɪl. ðə wʊlfs sɛndɪŋ keɪm əz ɪmədʒəz ə ɹʌnɪŋ əkɹɔs oʊpən filz, stɔks ʌv ɡɹeɪn bɹʌʃɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪz snaʊt. ən oʊpən skaɪ, ə kul bɹiz, ə θɹɪl ən lʌs fəɹ ædvɛntʃɝ. ðə sɛns ə nu ɹeɪn, ʌv waɪl pæstʃɝz.

If you are unhappy, Hopper sent, take your she and leave. If you do not wish to lead the pack, another will. The wolf's sending came as images of running across open fields, stalks of grain brushing along his snout. An open sky, a cool breeze, a thrill and lust for adventure. The scents of new rain, of wild pastures.

pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt ɪz tɑŋz ɪndə ðə koʊlz fəɹ ðə faɪnəl bɑɹ ʌv aɪɝn. ɪt bɝn ə dɪstənt, deɪnʒɝəs jɛloʊ. "aɪ kæn liv." hi hɛl ðə bɑɹ ʌp təwɔɹd ðə wʊlf. "ɪt wəd min ɡɪvɪŋ ɪn tə biɪŋ ə wʊlf.

Perrin reached his tongs into the coals for the final bar of iron. It burned a distant, dangerous yellow. "I can't leave." He held the bar up toward the wolf. "It would mean giving in to being a wolf.

ɪt wəd min luzɪŋ maɪsɛlf. aɪ woʊn də ðæt."

It would mean losing myself. I won't do that."

hi hɛl ðə nɪɹ-moʊltən stil bɪtwin ðɛm, ən hɑpɝ wɑtʃt ɪt, jɛloʊ pɪnpɹɪks ə laɪt ɹəflɛktɪŋ ɪn ðə wʊlfs aɪz. ðɪs dʒɹim wɑz soʊ ɑd. ɪn ðə pæst, pɛɹɪnz ɔɹɾənɛɹi dʒɹimz ən ðə wʊlf dʒɹim hæd bɪn sɛpɹət. wʌd ðɪs blɛndɪŋ min?

He held the near-molten steel between them, and Hopper watched it, yellow pinpricks of light reflecting in the wolf's eyes. This dream was so odd. In the past, Perrin's ordinary dreams and the wolf dream had been separate. What did this blending mean?

pɛɹɪn wɑz əfɹeɪd. hid kʌm tə ə pɹikɛɹiəs tʃɹus wɪð ðə wʊlf ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. ɡɹoʊɪŋ tu kloʊs tə ðə wʊlvz wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, bʌt ðət hædn pɹɪvɛntɪɾ ɪm tɝnɪŋ tə ðɛm wən sikɪŋ feɪl.

Perrin was afraid. He'd come to a precarious truce with the wolf inside of him. Growing too close to the wolves was dangerous, but that hadn't prevented him turning to them when seeking Faile.

ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ feɪl. ɪn duɪŋ soʊ, pɛɹɪn hæd nɪɹli ɡɔn mæd, ən hæɾ ivən tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɑpɝ.

Anything for Faile. In doing so, Perrin had nearly gone mad, and had even tried to kill Hopper.

pɛɹɪn wɑznt nɪɹli əz ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl əz hiɾ əsumd. ðə wʊlf wɪðɪn ɪm kəd stɪl ɹeɪn.

Perrin wasn't nearly as in control as he'd assumed. The wolf within him could still reign.

hɑpɝ jɔnd, lɛɾɪŋ ɪz tʌŋ lɑl. hi smɛld ə swiɾ əmjuzmənt.

Hopper yawned, letting his tongue loll. He smelled of sweet amusement.

"ðɪs ɪz nɑt fʌni." pɛɹɪn sɛt ðə faɪnəl bɑɹ əsaɪd wɪθaʊt wɝkɪŋ ɑn ɪt. ɪt kuld, teɪkɪŋ ɑn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə θɪn ɹɛktæŋɡəl, nɑɾ ənlaɪk ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋz ʌv ə hɪnʒ.

"This is not funny." Perrin set the final bar aside without working on it. It cooled, taking on the shape of a thin rectangle, not unlike the beginnings of a hinge.

pɹɑbləmz ɑɹ nɑɾ əmjuzɪŋ, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ əɡɹid. bʌt jə ɑɹ klaɪmɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ oʊvɝ ðə seɪm wɔl. kʌm. lɛɾ əs ɹʌn.

Problems are not amusing, Young Bull, Hopper agreed. But you are climbing back and forth over the same wall. Come. Let us run.

wʊlvz lɪvd ɪn ðə moʊmənt; ðoʊ ðeɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə pæst ən sim tə hæv ən ɑd sɛns fəɹ ðə fjutʃɝ, ðeɪ dɪdnt wɝi əbaʊɾ iðɝ. nɑɾ əz mɛn dɪd. wʊlvz ɹæn fɹi, tʃeɪsɪŋ ðə wɪnz. tə dʒɔɪn əm wəd bi tə ɪɡnɔɹ peɪn, sɑɹoʊ ən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. tə bi fɹi . . .

Wolves lived in the moment; though they remembered the past and seemed to have an odd sense for the future, they didn't worry about either. Not as men did. Wolves ran free, chasing the winds. To join them would be to ignore pain, sorrow and frustration. To be free . . .

ðət fɹiɾəm wəd kɑs pɛɹɪn tu mʌtʃ. hid luz feɪl, wəd luz ɪz vɛɹi sɛlf i dɪdnt wɑnə bi ə wʊlf. hi wɑntəd tə bi ə mæn. "ɪz ðəɹ ə weɪ tə ɹɪvɝs wʌɾ əz hæpən tə mi?"

That freedom would cost Perrin too much. He'd lose Faile, would lose his very self He didn't want to be a wolf. He wanted to be a man. "Is there a way to reverse what has happened to me?"

ɹɪvɝs? hɑpɝ kɑkt ɪz hɛd. tə ɡoʊ bækwɝd wɑz nɑɾ ə weɪ ʌv wʊlvz.

Reverse? Hopper cocked his head. To go backward was not a way of wolves.

"kæn aɪ . . ." pɛɹɪn stʃɹʌɡəl tə ɪkspleɪn. "kæn aɪ ɹʌn soʊ fɑɹ ðət ðə wʊlvz kænɑt hɪɹ mi?"

"Can I . . ." Perrin struggled to explain. "Can I run so far that the wolves cannot hear me?"

hɑpɝ sim kənfjuzd. noʊ. "kənfjuzd" dɪd nɑt kənveɪ ðə peɪn sɛndɪŋz ðət keɪm fɹəm hɑpɝ. nʌθɪŋnəs, ðə sɛn ə ɹɑɾɪŋ mit, wʊlvz haʊlɪŋ ɪn æɡəni. biɪŋ kʌɾ ɔf wɑz nɑɾ ə θɪŋ hɑpɝ kəd kənsiv.

Hopper seemed confused. No. "Confused" did not convey the pained sendings that came from Hopper. Nothingness, the scent of rotting meat, wolves howling in agony. Being cut off was not a thing Hopper could conceive.

pɛɹɪnz maɪnd ɡɹu mzi. waɪ hæɾ i stɑp fɔɹdʒɪŋ? hi hæd tə fɪnɪʃ. mæstɝ luhən wəd bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪd! ðoʊz lʌmps wɝ tɛɹəbəl. hi ʃəd haɪd ðɛm. kɹieɪt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ʃoʊ hi wɑz keɪpəbəl. hi kəd fɔɹdʒ. kʊdn hi?

Perrin's mind grew mzzy. Why had he stopped forging? He had to finish. Master Luhhan would be disappointed! Those lumps were terrible. He should hide them. Create something else, show he was capable. He could forge. Couldn't he?

ə hɪsɪŋ keɪm fɹəm bɪsaɪd hɪm. pɛɹɪn tɝnd, sɝpɹaɪz tə si ðət wʌn ə ðə kwɛntʃɪŋ bæɹəlz bɪsaɪd ðə hɑɹθ wɑz bɔɪlɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, hi θɔt. ðə fɝs pisəz aɪ fɪnɪʃt. aɪ dʒɹɑpt əm ɪn ðɛɹ.

A hissing came from beside him. Perrin turned, surprised to see that one of the quenching barrels beside the hearth was boiling. Of course, he thought. The first pieces I finished. I dropped them in there.

sʌɾənli æŋkʃəs, pɛɹɪn ɡɹæbd ɪz tɑŋz ən ɹitʃt ɪndə ðə tɝbjələnt wɔɾɝ, stim ɪnɡʌlfɪŋ ɪz feɪs. hi faʊn sʌmθɪŋ ət ðə bɑɾəm ən bɹɔɾ ɪɾ aʊt wɪð ɪz tɑŋz: ə tʃʌŋk ʌv waɪt-hɑt mɛɾəl.

Suddenly anxious, Perrin grabbed his tongs and reached into the turbulent water, steam engulfing his face. He found something at the bottom and brought it out with his tongs: a chunk of white-hot metal.

ðə ɡloʊ feɪɾəd. ðə tʃʌŋk wɑz æktʃəli  ə smɔl stil fɪɡjɝin ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɔl, θɪn mæn wɪð ə sɔɹd taɪd tə hɪz bæk. itʃ laɪn ɑn ðə fɪɡjɝ wɑz dɪteɪld, ðə ɹʌfəlz ə ðə ʃɝt, ðə lɛðɝ bænz ɑn ðə hɪlt ə ðə taɪni sɔɹd. bʌt ðə feɪs wɑz dɪstɔɹɾəd, ðə maʊθ oʊpən ɪn ə twɪstəd skɹim.

The glow faded. The chunk was actually a small steel figurine in the shape of a tall, thin man with a sword tied to his back. Each line on the figure was detailed, the ruffles of the shirt, the leather bands on the hilt of the tiny sword. But the face was distorted, the mouth open in a twisted scream.

ɛɹæm, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hɪz neɪm wɑz ɛɹæm.

Aram, Perrin thought. His name was Aram.

pɛɹɪn kʊdnt ʃoʊ ðɪs tə mæstɝ luhən! waɪ hæɾ i kɹieɪɾəd sətʃ ə θɪŋ?

Perrin couldn't show this to Master Luhhan! Why had he created such a thing?

ðə fɪɡjɝinz maʊθ oʊpən fɑɹðɝ, skɹimɪŋ saʊnləsli. pɛɹɪn kɹaɪɾ aʊt, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ðə tɑŋz ən dʒʌmpɪŋ bæk. ðə fɪɡjɝin fɛl tə ðə wʊd flɔɹ ən ʃæɾɝd.

The figurine's mouth opened farther, screaming soundlessly. Perrin cried out, dropping it from the tongs and jumping back. The figurine fell to the wood floor and shattered.

waɪ dʒju θɪŋk soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðət wʌn? hɑpɝ jɔn ə waɪd-dʒɔd wʊlf jɔn, tʌŋ kɝlɪŋ. ɪts kɑmən ðəɾ ə jʌŋ pʌp tʃælənʒɪz ðə pæk liɾɝ. hi wɑz fulɪʃ, ən jə dɪfiɾəd hɪm.

Why do you think so much about that one? Hopper yawned a wide-jawed wolf yawn, tongue curling. It is common that a young pup challenges the pack leader. He was foolish, and you defeated him.

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn wɪspɝd. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt kɑmən fəɹ hjumənz. nɑt fəɹ fɹɛnz."

"No," Perrin whispered. "It is not common for humans. Not for friends."

ðə wɔl ə ðə fɔɹdʒ sʌɾənli mɛltəɾ əweɪ, bɪkʌmɪŋ smoʊk. ɪt fɛl nætʃɹəl fəɹ ðət tə hæpən.

The wall of the forge suddenly melted away, becoming smoke. It felt natural for that to happen.

aʊtsaɪd, pɛɹɪn sɔ ən oʊpən, deɪlɪt stʃɹit. ə sɪɾi wɪð bɹoʊkən-wɪndoʊd ʃɑps.

Outside, Perrin saw an open, daylit street. A city with broken-windowed shops.

"meɪɾən," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Maiden," Perrin said.

ə smoʊki, tʃɹænslusən ɪmədʒ ə hɪmsɛlf stʊɾ aʊtsaɪd. ði ɪmədʒ wɔɹ noʊ koʊt; hɪz bɛɹ ɑɹmz bʌlʒd wɪð mʌsəlz. hi kɛpt ɪz bɪɹd ʃɔɹt, bʌɾ ɪt meɪɾ ɪm lʊk oʊldɝ, mɔɹ ɪntɛns. dɪd pɛɹɪn ɹɪli lʊk ðəɾ ɪmpoʊzɪŋ? ə skwɑt fɔɹtʃɹəs ʌv ə mæn wɪð ɡoʊldən aɪz ðət sim tə ɡloʊ, kæɹiɪŋ ə ɡlimɪŋ hæf-mun æks əz lɑɹdʒ əz ə mænz hɛd.

A smoky, translucent image of himself stood outside. The image wore no coat; his bare arms bulged with muscles. He kept his beard short, but it made him look older, more intense. Did Perrin really look that imposing? A squat fortress of a man with golden eyes that seemed to glow, carrying a gleaming half-moon axe as large as a man's head.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðəɾ æks. pɛɹɪn stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə smɪθi, pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə ʃæɾoʊi vɝʒən ə hɪmsɛlf. wən i dɪd, hi bɪkeɪm ðəɾ ɪmədʒ, æks hɛvi ɪn ɪz hænd, wɝk kloʊðz vænɪʃɪŋ ən bæɾəl ɡɪɹ ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ ɪt.

There was something wrong about that axe. Perrin stepped out of the smithy, passing through the shadowy version of himself. When he did, he became that image, axe heavy in his hand, work clothes vanishing and battle gear replacing it.

hi tʊk ɔf ɹʌnɪŋ. jɛs, ðɪs wɑz meɪɾən. ðəɹ wɝ il ɪn ðə stʃɹits. hid lɪv ðɪs bæɾəl, ðoʊ hi wɑz mʌtʃ kɑmɝ ðɪs taɪm. bɪfɔɹ, hid bɪn lɔst ɪn ðə θɹɪl ə faɪɾɪŋ ən ə sikɪŋ feɪl. hi stɑpt ɪn ðə stʃɹit. "ðɪs ɪz ɹɔŋ. aɪ kæɹid maɪ hæmɝ ɪndə meɪɾən. aɪ θɹu ði æks əweɪ."

He took off running. Yes, this was Maiden. There were Aiel in the streets. He'd lived this battle, though he was much calmer this time. Before, he'd been lost in the thrill of fighting and of seeking Faile. He stopped in the street. "This is wrong. I carried my hammer into Maiden. I threw the axe away."

ə hɔɹn əɹ ə huf, jʌŋ bʊl, dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ wɪtʃ wʌn jə jus tə hʌnt? hɑpɝ wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌnlɪt stʃɹit bɪsaɪd hɪm.

A horn or a hoof, Young Bull, does it matter which one you use to hunt? Hopper was sitting in the sunlit street beside him.

"jɛs. ɪt mæɾɝz. ɪt dʌz tə mi."

"Yes. It matters. It does to me."

ən jɛt jə juz əm ðə seɪm weɪ.

And yet you use them the same way.

ə pɛɹ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ il əpɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ. ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə ðə lɛft, sʌmθɪŋ pɛɹɪn kʊdn si. hi ɹæn tə ətæk ðɛm.

A pair of Shaido Aiel appeared around a corner. They were watching something to the left, something Perrin couldn't see. He ran to attack them.

hi ʃɪɹd θɹu ðə tʃɪn ʌv wʌn, ðən swʌŋ ðə spaɪk ɑn ði æks ɪndə ðə tʃɛst ə ði ʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz ə bɹuɾəl, tɛɹəbəl ətæk, ən ɔl θɹi ʌv əm ɛndəɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɪt tʊk sɛvɹəl stæbz fɹəm ðə spaɪk tə kɪl ðə sɛkənd ʃeɪɾoʊ.

He sheared through the chin of one, then swung the spike on the axe into the chest of the other. It was a brutal, terrible attack, and all three of them ended on the ground. It took several stabs from the spike to kill the second Shaido.

pɛɹɪn stʊɾ ʌp. hi dɪd ɹɪmɛmbɝ kɪlɪŋ ðoʊz tu il, ðoʊ hi hæd dʌn ɪt wɪð hæmɝ ən naɪf. hi dɪdn ɹəɡɹɛt ðɛɹ dɛθs. səmtaɪmz ə mæn niɾəd tə faɪt, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. dɛθ wɑz tɛɹəbəl, bʌt ðət dɪdn stɑp ɪt fɹəm biɪŋ nɛsəsɛɹi. ɪn fækt, ɪt hæd bɪn wʌndɝfəl tə klæʃ wɪð ði il. hid fɛlt laɪk ə wʊlf ɑn ðə hʌnt.

Perrin stood up. He did remember killing those two Aiel, though he had done it with hammer and knife. He didn't regret their deaths. Sometimes a man needed to fight, and that was that. Death was terrible, but that didn't stop it from being necessary. In fact, it had been wonderful to clash with the Aiel. He'd felt like a wolf on the hunt.

wən pɛɹɪn fɔt, hi keɪm kloʊs tə bɪkʌmɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛls. ən ðət wɑz deɪnʒɝəs.

When Perrin fought, he came close to becoming someone else. And that was dangerous.

hi lʊkt əkjuzɪŋli ət hɑpɝ, hu laʊnʒd ɑn ə stʃɹit kɔɹnɝ. "waɪ ɑɹ jə meɪkɪŋ mi dʒɹim ðɪs?"

He looked accusingly at Hopper, who lounged on a street corner. "Why are you making me dream this?"

meɪkɪŋ ju? hɑpɝ æskt. ðɪs ɪz nɑt maɪ dʒɹim, jʌŋ bʊl. dʒju si maɪ dʒɔz ɑn jəɹ nɛk, fɔɹsɪŋ jə tə θɪŋk ɪt?

Making you? Hopper asked. This is not my dream, Young Bull. Do you see my jaws on your neck, forcing you to think it?

pɛɹɪnz æks stʃɹimd wɪð blʌd. hi nu wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ nɛkst. hi tɝnd. fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, ɛɹæm əpɹoʊtʃt, mɝɾɝ ɪn ɪz aɪz. hæf ə ðə fɔɹmɝ tɪŋkɝz feɪs wɑz koʊɾəd ɪn blʌd, ən ɪt dʒɹɪp fɹəm ɪz tʃɪn, steɪnɪŋ ɪz ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊt.

Perrin's axe streamed with blood. He knew what was coming next. He turned. From behind, Aram approached, murder in his eyes. Half of the former Tinker's face was coated in blood, and it dripped from his chin, staining his red-striped coat.

ɛɹæm swʌŋ ɪz sɔɹd fəɹ pɛɹɪnz nɛk, ðə stil hɪsɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. pɛɹɪn stɛp bæk. hi ɹəfjuz tə faɪt ðə bɔɪ əɡɛn.

Aram swung his sword for Perrin's neck, the steel hissing in the air. Perrin stepped back. He refused to fight the boy again.

ðə ʃæɾoʊi vɝʒən ə hɪmsɛlf splɪɾ ɔf, livɪŋ ðə ɹil pɛɹɪn ɪn ɪz blæksmɪθs kloʊðɪŋ. ðə ʃædoʊ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd bloʊz wɪð ɛɹæm. ðə pɹɑfəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə mi . . . jəɹ ɹɪli ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. . . . wʌn əv tə ɹɛskju ðə leɪɾi feɪl fɹəm ju. . . .

The shadowy version of himself split off, leaving the real Perrin in his blacksmith's clothing. The shadow exchanged blows with Aram. The Prophet explained it to me . . . You're really Shadowspawn. . . . 1 have to rescue the Lady Faile from you. . . .

ðə ʃæɾoʊi pɛɹɪn tʃeɪnʒd, sʌɾənli, ɪndə ə wʊlf. ɪt lɛpt, fɝ nɪɹli əz dɑɹk əz ðəɾ ʌv ə ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝ, ən ɹɪpt aʊɾ ɛɹæmz θɹoʊt.

The shadowy Perrin changed, suddenly, into a wolf. It leaped, fur nearly as dark as that of a Shadowbrother, and ripped out Aram's throat.

"noʊ! ɪt dɪdn hæpən laɪk ðæt!"

"No! It didn't happen like that!"

ɪts ə dʒɹim, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

It is a dream, Hopper sent.

"bʌɾ aɪ dɪdn kɪl hɪm," pɛɹɪn pɹətɛstəd. "sʌm il ʃɑɾ ɪm wɪð æɹoʊz ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ. . . ."

"But I didn't kill him," Perrin protested. "Some Aiel shot him with arrows right before. . . ."

ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ɛɹæm wʊɾə kɪl pɛɹɪn.

Right before Aram would have killed Perrin.

ðə hɔɹn, ðə huf, əɹ ðə tuθ, hɑpɝ sɛnt, tɝnɪŋ ən æmbəlɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə bɪldɪŋ. ɪts wɔl vænɪʃt, ɹɪvilɪŋ mæstɝ luhənz smɪθi ɪnsaɪd. dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ? ðə dɛɾ ɑɹ dɛd. tu-lɛɡz də nɑt kʌm hɪɹ, nɑt juʒəwəli, wʌns ðeɪ daɪ. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ɪts ðət ðeɪ ɡoʊ.

The horn, the hoof, or the tooth, Hopper sent, turning and ambling toward a building. Its wall vanished, revealing Master Luhhan's smithy inside. Does it matter? The dead are dead. Two-legs do not come here, not usually, once they die. I do not know where it is that they go.

pɛɹɪn lʊk daʊn əɾ ɛɹæmz bɑɾi. "aɪ ʃʊɾə teɪkən ðət ful sɔɹd fɹəm ɪm ðə moʊmən i pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp. aɪ ʃʊɾə sɛn ɪm bæk tə hɪz fæmli."

Perrin looked down at Aram's body. "I should have taken that fool sword from him the moment he picked it up. I should have sent him back to his family."

dʌz nɑɾ ə kʌb dɪzɝv ɪz fæŋz? hɑpɝ æskt, dʒɛnjəwənli kənfjuzd. waɪ wəd jə pʊl ðɛm?

Does not a cub deserve his fangs? Hopper asked, genuinely confused. Why would you pull them?

"ɪɾ ɪz ə θɪŋ ə mɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"It is a thing of men," Perrin said.

θɪŋz ə tu-lɛɡz, ʌv mɛn. ɔlweɪz, ɪts ə θɪŋ ə mɛn tə ju. wʌɾ ə θɪŋz ʌv wʊlvz?

Things of two-legs, of men. Always, it is a thing of men to you. What of things of wolves?

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ə wʊlf."

"I am not a wolf."

hɑpɝ ɛntɝd ðə fɔɹdʒ, ən pɛɹɪn ɹɪlʌktənli fɑloʊd. ðə bæɹəl wɑz stɪl bɔɪlɪŋ. ðə wɔl ɹɪtɝnd, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz wʌns əɡɛn wɛɹɪŋ ɪz lɛðɝ vɛst ən eɪpɹən, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz tɑŋz.

Hopper entered the forge, and Perrin reluctantly followed. The barrel was still boiling. The wall returned, and Perrin was once again wearing his leather vest and apron, holding his tongs.

hi stɛpt oʊvɝ ən pʊld aʊɾ ənʌðɝ fɪɡjɝin. ðɪs wʌn wɑz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə tɑɾ ɑlkɑɹ. əz ɪt kuld, pɛɹɪn faʊn ðət ðə feɪs wɑzn dɪstɔɹɾəd laɪk ɛɹæmz, ðoʊ ðə loʊɝ hæf ə ðə fɪɡjɝin wɑz ənfɔɹmd, stɪl ə blɑk ə mɛɾəl. ðə fɪɡjɝin kəntɪnjud tə ɡloʊ, feɪnli ɹɛɾɪʃ, æftɝ pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪt daʊn ɑn ðə flɔɹ. hi θɹʌst ɪz tɑŋz bæk ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ ən pʊl fɹi ə fɪɡjɝ ə dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ, ðən wʌn ʌv ɑzi ælθoʊn.

He stepped over and pulled out another figurine. This one was in the shape of Tod al'Caar. As it cooled, Perrin found that the face wasn't distorted like Aram's, though the lower half of the figurine was unformed, still a block of metal. The figurine continued to glow, faintly reddish, after Perrin set it down on the floor. He thrust his tongs back into the water and pulled free a figure of Jori Congar, then one of Azi al'Thone.

pɛɹɪn wɛn tə ðə bʌbəlɪŋ bæɹəl taɪm ən taɪm əɡɛn, pʊlɪŋ aʊt fɪɡjɝin æftɝ fɪɡjɝin. æftɝ ðə weɪ ʌv dʒɹimz, fɛtʃɪŋ əm ɔl tʊk boʊθ ə bɹif sɛkən ən wʌt sim laɪk aʊɝz. wən i fɪnɪʃt, hʌnʒɹədz ə fɪɡjɝinz stʊɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ feɪsɪŋ hɪm. wɑtʃɪŋ. itʃ stil fɪɡjɝ wɑz lɪt wɪð ə taɪni faɪɝ ɪnsaɪd, əz ɪf weɪɾɪŋ tə fil ðə fɔɹdʒɝz hæmɝ.

Perrin went to the bubbling barrel time and time again, pulling out figurine after figurine. After the way of dreams, fetching them all took both a brief second and what seemed like hours. When he finished, hundreds of figurines stood on the floor facing him. Watching. Each steel figure was lit with a tiny fire inside, as if waiting to feel the forger's hammer.

bʌt fɪɡjɝinz laɪk ðɪs wʊdn bi fɔɹdʒd; ðeɪd bi kæst. "wʌt dʌz ɪt min?" pɛɹɪn sæt daʊn ɑn ə stul.

But figurines like this wouldn't be forged; they'd be cast. "What does it mean?" Perrin sat down on a stool.

min? hɑpɝ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ ɪn ə wʊlf læf. ɪt minz ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni lɪɾəl mɛn ɑn ðə flɔɹ, nʌn ʌv wɪtʃ jə kən it. jəɹ kaɪn ɪz tu fɑn ə ɹɑks ən wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðɛm.

Mean? Hopper opened his mouth in a wolf laugh. It means there are many little men on the floor, none of which you can eat. Your kind is too fond of rocks and what is inside of them.

ðə fɪɡjɝinz simd əkjuzɪŋ. ɝaʊn əm leɪ ðə bɹoʊkən ʃɑɹdz ʌv ɛɹæm. ðoʊz pisəz sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ. ðə ʃæɾɝd hænz bɪɡæn wɝkɪŋ, klɔɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə ʃɑɹdz ɔl bɪkeɪm lɪɾəl hænz, klaɪmɪŋ təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ hɪm.

The figurines seemed accusing. Around them lay the broken shards of Aram. Those pieces seemed to be growing larger. The shattered hands began working, clawing on the ground. The shards all became little hands, climbing toward Perrin, reaching for him.

pɛɹɪn ɡæspt, lipɪŋ tə hɪz fit. hi hɝd læftɝ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ɹɪŋɪŋ kloʊsɝ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə bɪldɪŋ. hɑpɝ dʒʌmpt, slæmɪŋ ɪndə hɪm. ən ðən . . .

Perrin gasped, leaping to his feet. He heard laughter in the distance, ringing closer, shaking the building. Hopper jumped, slamming into him. And then . . .

pɛɹɪn stɑɹɾəd əweɪk. hi wɑz bæk ɪn ɪz tɛnt, ɪn ðə fild wɛɹ ðeɪd bɪn kæmp fəɹ ə fju deɪz naʊ. ðeɪd ɹʌn əkɹɔs ə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl ðə wik bɪfɔɹ ðət hæd kɑzd æŋɡɹi ɹɛd, ɔɪli sɝpəns tə wɪɡəl fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn ɔl θɹu kæmp. sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd wɝ sɪk fɹəm ðɛɹ baɪts; ɛɛs sədaɪ hilɪŋ hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə kip moʊst ə ðɛm əlaɪv, bʌt nɑt ɹɪstɔɹ əm kəmplitli.

Perrin started awake. He was back in his tent, in the field where they'd been camped for a few days now. They'd run across a bubble of evil the week before that had caused angry red, oily serpents to wiggle from the ground all through camp. Several hundred were sick from their bites; Aes Sedai Healing had been enough to keep most of them alive, but not restore them completely.

feɪl slɛp bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn, pisfəl. aʊtsaɪd, wʌn ə hɪz mɛn tæpt ə poʊs tə kaʊn ɔf ði aʊɝ.

Faile slept beside Perrin, peaceful. Outside, one of his men tapped a post to count off the hour.

θɹi tæps. stɪl aʊɝz əntɪl dɔn.

Three taps. Still hours until dawn.

pɛɹɪnz hɑɹt paʊndɪd sɔfli, ən i ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɪz bɛɹ tʃɛst. hi hæf-ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ɑɹmi ʌv taɪni mɛɾəl hænz tə kɹɔl aʊt fɹəm bɪniθ ɪz bɛdʒɹoʊl.

Perrin's heart pounded softly, and he raised a hand to his bare chest. He half-expected an army of tiny metal hands to crawl out from beneath his bedroll.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, hi fɔɹst ɪz aɪz kloʊzd ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪlæks. ðɪs taɪm, slip wɑz vɛɹi ɪlusɪv.

Eventually, he forced his eyes closed and tried to relax. This time, sleep was very elusive.

ɡɹeɪndəl sɪpt əɾ əɹ waɪn, wɪtʃ ɡlɪsən ɪn ə ɡɑblət tʃɹɪmd wɪð ə wɛb ə sɪlvɝ ɝaʊn ðə saɪdz. ðə ɡɑblət hæd bɪn kɹæftɪd wɪð dʒɹɑps ə blʌd kɑɾ ɪn ə ɹɪŋ pæɾɝn wɪðɪn ðə kɹɪstəl.

Graendal sipped at her wine, which glistened in a goblet trimmed with a web of silver around the sides. The goblet had been crafted with drops of blood caught in a ring pattern within the crystal.

fɹoʊzən fɝɛvɝ, taɪni bʌbəlz ə bɹɪljən ɹɛd.

Frozen forever, tiny bubbles of brilliant red.

"wi ʃəd bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ," ɝæŋɡɝ sɛd, laʊnʒɪŋ ɑn ðə ʃeɪz ən aɪɪŋ wʌn ʌv ɡɹeɪndəlz pɛts wɪð ə pɹɛɾətɔɹi hʌŋɡɝ əz i pæst. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ jə stæn ɪt, steɪɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪvɛns, laɪk səm skɑlɝ hoʊld ʌp ɪn ə dʌsti kɔɹnɝ."

"We should be doing something," Aran'gar said, lounging on the chaise and eyeing one of Graendal's pets with a predatory hunger as he passed. "I don't know how you stand it, staying so far from important events, like some scholar holed up in a dusty corner."

ɡɹeɪndəl ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ. ə skɑlɝ? ɪn səm dʌsti kɔɹnɝ? nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ wɑz mɑɾəst kəmpɛɹd tə səm pæləsəz ʃi hæd noʊn, dʊɹɪŋ ðə pɹiviəs eɪdʒ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ə hʌvəl. ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz wɝ faɪn, ðə wɔlz bɛɹɪŋ ən ɑɹtʃɪŋ pæɾɝn ə θɪk, dɑɹk hɑɹdwʊdz, ðə mɑɹbəl ə ðə flɔɹ spɑɹklɪŋ wɪð ɪnleɪd tʃɪps ə mʌðɝ-ʌv-pɝl ən ɡoʊld.

Graendal arched an eyebrow. A scholar? In some dusty corner? Natrin's Barrow was modest compared to some palaces she had known, during the previous Age, but it was hardly a hovel. The furnishings were fine, the walls bearing an arching pattern of thick, dark hardwoods, the marble of the floor sparkling with inlaid chips of mother-of-pearl and gold.

ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹəvoʊk hɝ. ɡɹeɪndəl pʊt ði ɪɹɪteɪʃən aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪnd. ðə faɪɝ bɝn loʊ ɪn ðə hɑɹθ, bʌt ðə pɛɹ ə dɔɹz -  liɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɑntu ə fɔɹɾəfaɪd wɔkweɪ θɹi stɔɹiz ɪn ði ɛɹ - wɝ oʊpən, lɛɾɪŋ ɪn ə kɹɪsp maʊntən bɹiz. ʃi ɹɛɹli lɛft ə wɪndoʊ əɹ dɔɹ oʊpən tə ði aʊtsaɪd, bʌt tədeɪ ʃi laɪk ðə kɑntʃɹæst: wɔɹmθ fɹəm wʌn saɪd, ə kul bɹiz fɹəm ði ʌðɝ.

Aran'gar was just trying to provoke her. Graendal put the irritation out of her mind. The fire burned low in the hearth, but the pair of doors -  leading out onto a fortified walkway three stories in the air - were open, letting in a crisp mountain breeze. She rarely left a window or door open to the outside, but today she liked the contrast: warmth from one side, a cool breeze from the other.

laɪf wɑz əbaʊt filɪŋ. tʌtʃəz ɑn jəɹ skɪn, boʊθ pæʃənəɾ ən aɪsi. ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ðə nɔɹməl, ði ævɝɪdʒ, ðə lukwɔɹm.

Life was about feeling. Touches on your skin, both passionate and icy. Anything other than the normal, the average, the lukewarm.

"ɑɹ jə lɪsnɪŋ tə mi?" ɝæŋɡɝ æskt.

"Are you listening to me?" Aran'gar asked.

"aɪ ɔlweɪz lɪsən," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ əsaɪɾ əɹ ɡɑbləɾ əz ʃi sæɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn ʃeɪz. ʃi wɔɹ ə ɡoʊldən, ɪnvɛləpɪŋ dʒɹɛs, ʃɪɹ bʌt bʌɾənd tə ðə nɛk. wʌt mɑɹvələs fæʃənz ðiz dəmɑni hæd, aɪdil fəɹ tizɪŋ waɪl ɹɪvilɪŋ.

"I always listen," Graendal said, setting aside her goblet as she sat on her own chaise. She wore a golden, enveloping dress, sheer but buttoned to the neck. What marvelous fashions these Domani had, ideal for teasing while revealing.

"aɪ loʊð biɪŋ soʊ ɹimuv fɹəm θɪŋz," ɝæŋɡɝ kəntɪnjud. "ðɪs eɪdʒ ɪz ɪksaɪɾɪŋ. pɹɪməɾɪv pipəl kən bi soʊ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ." ðə vəlʌptʃəwəs, aɪvɝi-skɪnd wʊmən ɑɹtʃt əɹ bæk, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ɑɹmz təwɔɹd ðə wɔl. "wɝ mɪsɪŋ ɔl ə ði ɪksaɪtmənt."

"I loathe being so removed from things," Aran'gar continued. "This Age is exciting. Primitive people can be so interesting." The voluptuous, ivory-skinned woman arched her back, stretching arms toward the wall. "We're missing all of the excitement."

"ɪksaɪtmən ɪz bɛs vjud fɹəm ə dɪstəns," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "aɪ wəd θɪŋk juɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt."

"Excitement is best viewed from a distance," Graendal said. "I would think you'd understand that."

ɝæŋɡɝ fɛl saɪlənt. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd nɑt bɪn plizd wɪð əɹ fəɹ luzɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ʌv ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ.

Aran'gar fell silent. The Great Lord had not been pleased with her for losing control of Egwene al'Vere.

"wɛl," ɝæŋɡɝ sɛd, stændɪŋ. "ɪf ðəɾ ɪz jəɹ θɔɾ ɑn ɪt, əl sik mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ivnɪŋ spɔɹt."

"Well," Aran'gar said, standing. "If that is your thought on it, I will seek more interesting evening sport."

hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kul; pɝhæps ðɛɹ əlaɪəns wɑz wɛɹɪŋ θɪn. ɪn ðət keɪs, ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ɹiɪnfɔɹsmənt. ɡɹeɪndəl oʊpən hɝsɛlf ən æksɛptɪd ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz dɑmənəns ə hɝ, filɪŋ ðə θɹɪlɪŋ ɛkstəsi ʌv ɪz paʊɝ, hɪz pæʃən, hɪz vɛɹi sʌbstəns. ɪt wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪntɑksɪkeɪɾɪŋ ðən ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ðɪs ɹeɪdʒɪŋ tɔɹən ə faɪɝ.

Her voice was cool; perhaps their alliance was wearing thin. In that case, it was time for reinforcement. Graendal opened herself and accepted the Great Lord's dominance of her, feeling the thrilling ecstasy of his power, his passion, his very substance. It was so much more intoxicating than the One Power, this raging torrent of fire.

ɪt θɹɛɾənd tə oʊvɝwɛlm ən kənsum hɝ, ən dɪspaɪt biɪŋ fɪld wɪð ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ, ʃi kəd tʃænəl oʊnli ə θɪn tʃɹɪkəl ʌv ɪt. ə ɡɪf tə hɝ fɹəm mɔɹaɪɾɪn. noʊ, fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. bɛs nɑt tə bɪɡɪn əsoʊsieɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz tu ɪn əɹ maɪnd. fəɹ naʊ, mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɑz nɛbli. fəɹ naʊ oʊnli.

It threatened to overwhelm and consume her, and despite being filled with the True Power, she could channel only a thin trickle of it. A gift to her from Moridin. No, from the Great Lord. Best not to begin associating those two in her mind. For now, Moridin was Nae'blis. For now only.

ɡɹeɪndəl woʊv ə ɹɪbən ʌv ɛɹ. wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ wɑz sɪməlɝ, jɛt nɑɾ aɪdɛntɪkəl, tə wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ə wiv ə ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ wəɾ ɔfən fʌŋkʃən ɪn ə slaɪtli dɪfɹənt weɪ, əɹ əv ən ʌnæntɪsəpeɪɾɪd saɪɾ ɪfɛkt. ən ðəɹ wɝ səm wivz ðət kəɾ oʊnli bi kɹæftɪd baɪ ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ.

Graendal wove a ribbon of Air. Working with the True Power was similar, yet not identical, to working with the One Power. A weave of the True Power would often function in a slightly different way, or have an unanticipated side effect. And there were some weaves that could only be crafted by the True Power.

ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ɛsəns fɔɹs ðə pæɾɝn, stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪɾ ən livɪŋ ɪt skɑɹd. ivən sʌmθɪŋ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ hæd dɪzaɪn tə bi ɪtɝnəl kəd bi ənɹævəl juzɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ɛnɝdʒiz. ɪt bɪspoʊk ən ɪtɝnəl tʃɹuθ -  sʌmθɪŋ əz kloʊs tə biɪŋ seɪkɹəɾ əz ɡɹeɪndəl wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛpt. wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ kəd bɪld, ðə dɑɹk wʌn kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ.

The Great Lord's essence forced the Pattern, straining it and leaving it scarred. Even something the Creator had designed to be eternal could be unraveled using the Dark One's energies. It bespoke an eternal truth -  something as close to being sacred as Graendal was willing to accept. Whatever the Creator could build, the Dark One could destroy.

ʃi sneɪkt əɹ ɹɪbən ʌv ɛɹ θɹu ðə ɹum təwɔɹɾ ɝæŋɡɝ. ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən hæd stɛpt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə bælkəni; ɡɹeɪndəl fɝbeɪd ðə kɹieɪʃən ʌv ɡeɪtweɪz ɪnsaɪd, lɛs ðeɪ dæmədʒ əɹ pɛts əɹ əɹ fɝnɪʃɪŋz. ɡɹeɪndəl lɪftəd ðə ɹɪbən ʌv ɛɹ ʌp tə ɝæŋɡɝz tʃik ən kɝɛst ɪt dɛləkətli.

She snaked her ribbon of Air through the room toward Aran'gar. The other Chosen had stepped out onto the balcony; Graendal forbade the creation of gateways inside, lest they damage her pets or her furnishings. Graendal lifted the ribbon of Air up to Aran'gar's cheek and caressed it delicately.

ɝæŋɡɝ fɹoʊz. ʃi tɝnd, səspɪʃəs, bʌɾ ɪt tʊk oʊnli ə moʊmən fəɹ əɹ aɪz tə oʊpən waɪd. ʃi wʊdn əv fɛl ðə ɡus bʌmps ɑn əɹ ɑɹmz tə ɪndəkeɪt ɡɹeɪndəl wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ. ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ ɡeɪv noʊ hɪnt, noʊ saɪn. meɪl əɹ fimeɪl, noʊ wʌn kəd si əɹ sɛns ðə wivz - nɑɾ ənlɛs i əɹ ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɹæntəd ðə pɹɪvlədʒ ə tʃænəlɪŋ ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ.

Arangar froze. She turned, suspicious, but it took only a moment for her eyes to open wide. She wouldn't have felt the goose bumps on her arms to indicate Graendal was channeling. The True Power gave no hint, no sign. Male or female, no one could see or sense the weaves - not unless he or she had been granted the privilege of channeling the True Power.

"wʌt?" ðə wʊmən æskt. "haʊ? mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɪz - "

"What?" the woman asked. "How? Moridin is - "

"nɛbli," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "jɛs. bʌt wʌns ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz feɪvɝ ɪn ðɪs ɹəɡɑɹd wɑz nɑt kənfaɪn tə ðə nɛbli." ʃi kəntɪnjud tə kɝɛs ɝæŋɡɝz tʃik, ən ðə wʊmən flʌʃt.

"Nae'blis," Graendal said. "Yes. But once the Great Lord's favor in this regard was not confined to the Nae'blis." She continued to caress Arangar's cheek, and the woman flushed.

ɝæŋɡɝ, laɪk ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən, lʌstɪd fəɹ ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ waɪl fɪɹɪŋ ɪɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm -  deɪnʒɝəs, plɛʒɝəbəl, sɪdʌktɪv. wən ɡɹeɪndəl wɪθdʒɹu hɝ laɪn ʌv ɛɹ, ɝæŋɡɝ stɛp bæk ɪndə ðə ɹum ən ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ ʃeɪz, ðən sɛnt wʌn ʌv ɡɹeɪndəlz pɛts tə fɛtʃ əɹ tɔɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Arangar, like the other Chosen, lusted for the True Power while fearing it at the same time -  dangerous, pleasurable, seductive. When Graendal withdrew her line of Air, Arangar stepped back into the room and returned to her chaise, then sent one of Graendal's pets to fetch her toy Aes Sedai.

lʌst stɪl bɝn ɝæŋɡɝz tʃiks; laɪkli ʃi wəd juz dɛlænə tə dɪstʃɹæk hɝsɛlf. ɝæŋɡɝ sim tə faɪn ɪɾ əmjuzɪŋ tə fɔɹs ðə hoʊmli ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪndə səbsɝviəns.

Lust still burned Arangar's cheeks; likely she would use Delana to distract herself. Arangar seemed to find it amusing to force the homely Aes Sedai into subservience.

dɛlænə ɝaɪv moʊməns leɪɾɝ; ʃi ɔlweɪz ɹɪmeɪnd nɪɹbaɪ. ðə ʃaɪn-ɛɹən wʊmən wɑz peɪl- hɛɹɾ ən staʊt, wɪð θɪk lɪmz. ɡɹeɪndəlz lɪps tɝn daʊn. sətʃ ən ʌnpɹɛɾi θɪŋ. nɑt laɪk ɝæŋɡɝ hɝsɛlf. ʃiɾ əv meɪɾ ən aɪdil pɛt. meɪbi sʌmdeɪ ɡɹeɪndəl wəɾ əv ðə tʃæns tə meɪk əɹ ɪndə wʌn.

Delana arrived moments later; she always remained nearby. The Shien-aran woman was pale- haired and stout, with thick limbs. Graendal's lips turned down. Such an unpretty thing. Not like Arangar herself. She'd have made an ideal pet. Maybe someday Graendal would have the chance to make her into one.

ɝæŋɡɝ ən dɛlænə bɪɡæn tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ əfɛkʃənz ɑn ðə ʃeɪz. ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz ɪnseɪʃəbəl, ə fækt ɡɹeɪndəl hæɾ ɛksplɔɪɾəd ɑn numɝəs əkeɪʒənz, ðə lʊɹ ə ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ biɪŋ oʊnli ðə leɪɾəst. ʌv kɔɹs, ɡɹeɪndəl ɛndʒɔɪd plɛʒɝz hɝsɛlf, bʌt ʃi meɪd sɝɾən ðət pipəl θɔt ʃi wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ sɛlf-ɪndʌlʒənt ðən ʃi wɑz. ɪf jə nu wʌt pipəl ɪkspɛktəd jə tə bi, jə kəd juz ðoʊz ɛkspɛkteɪʃənz. ɪt -  ɡɹeɪndəl fɹoʊz əz ən əlɑɹm wɛn ɔf ɪn əɹ ɪɹz, ðə saʊn ə kɹæʃɪŋ weɪvz biɾɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɝæŋɡɝ kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ plɛʒɝz; ʃi kʊdn hɪɹ ðə saʊnd. ðə wiv wɑz vɛɹi spəsɪfɪk, pleɪst wɛɹ əɹ sɝvəns kəd tʃɹɪp ɪt tə ɡɪv əɹ wɔɹnɪŋ.

Arangar and Delana began to exchange affections on the chaise. Arangar was insatiable, a fact Graendal had exploited on numerous occasions, the lure of the True Power being only the latest. Of course, Graendal enjoyed pleasures herself, but she made certain that people thought she was far more self-indulgent than she was. If you knew what people expected you to be, you could use those expectations. It -  Graendal froze as an alarm went off in her ears, the sound of crashing waves beating against one another. Arangar continued her pleasures; she couldn't hear the sound. The weave was very specific, placed where her servants could trip it to give her warning.

ɡɹeɪndəl klaɪm tə hɝ fit, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ɡɪvɪŋ noʊ ɪndəkeɪʃən ə ɝdʒənsi. ət ðə dɔɹ, ʃi sɛn ə fju ʌv əɹ pɛts ɪn tə hɛlp dɪstʃɹækt ɝæŋɡɝ. bɛs tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə skoʊp ə ðə pɹɑbləm bɪfɔɹ ɪnvɑlvɪŋ hɝ.

Graendal climbed to her feet, strolling around the side of the room, giving no indication of urgency. At the door, she sent a few of her pets in to help distract Arangar. Best to discover the scope of the problem before involving her.

ɡɹeɪndəl wɔk daʊn ə hɔlweɪ hʌŋ wɪð ɡoʊldən ʃændəlɪz ən ɔɹnəmɛntɪd wɪð mɪɹɝz.

Graendal walked down a hallway hung with golden chandeliers and ornamented with mirrors.

ʃi wɑz hæfweɪ daʊn ə stɛɹwɛl wən ɡɝumænd - ðə kæptən ə hɝ pæləs ɡɑɹd - keɪm bʌsəlɪŋ ʌp. hi wɑz sɑldəiən, ə dɪstən kʌzən ə ðə kwin, ən wɔɹ ə θɪk mʌstæʃ ɑn ɪz lin, hænsəm feɪs. kəmpʌlʃən hæd meɪɾ ɪm ʌɾɝli lɔɪəl, ʌv kɔɹs.

She was halfway down a stairwell when Garumand - the captain of her palace guard - came bustling up. He was Saldaean, a distant cousin of the Queen, and wore a thick mustache on his lean, handsome face. Compulsion had made him utterly loyal, of course.

"ɡɹeɪt leɪɾi," hi sɛd, pæntɪŋ. "ə mæn əz bɪn kæptʃɝɾ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə pæləs. maɪ mɛn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪm əz ə maɪnɝ lɔɹd fɹəm bændɑɹ ɛbən, ə mɛmbɝ ə haʊs ɹæmʃələn."

"Great Lady," he said, panting. "A man has been captured approaching the palace. My men recognize him as a minor lord from Bandar Eban, a member of House Ramshalan."

ɡɹeɪndəl fɹaʊnd, ðən weɪv fəɹ ɡɝumæn tə fɑloʊ əz ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ tə wʌn ə hɝ ɑɾiəns tʃeɪmbɝz - ə smɔl, wɪndoʊləs ɹum dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɪn kɹɪmzən. ʃi woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, ðən sɛnt ɡɝumæn tə bɹɪŋ ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ.

Graendal frowned, then waved for Garumand to follow as she made her way to one of her audience chambers - a small, windowless room decorated in crimson. She wove a ward against eavesdropping, then sent Garumand to bring the intruder.

sun, hi ɹɪtɝnd wɪð səm ɡɑɹdz ən ə dəmɑni mæn dʒɹɛst ɪn bɹaɪt ɡɹinz ən bluz, ə bjuɾi mɑɹk ʃeɪp laɪk ə bɛl ɑn ɪz tʃik. hɪz nit, ʃɔɹt bɪɹd wɑz taɪd wɪð taɪni bɛlz, ən ðeɪ dʒɪŋɡəld əz ðə ɡɑɹdz ʃʌvd ɪm fɔɹwɝd. hi bɹʌʃt ɔf ɪz ɑɹmz, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə soʊlʒɝz, ən stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪz ɹʌfəld ʃɝt. "æm aɪ tə ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ aɪ hæv bɪn dɪlɪvɝd tə - "

Soon, he returned with some guards and a Domani man dressed in bright greens and blues, a beauty mark shaped like a bell on his cheek. His neat, short beard was tied with tiny bells, and they jingled as the guards shoved him forward. He brushed off his arms, glaring at the soldiers, and straightened his ruffled shirt. "Am I to understand that I have been delivered to - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə tʃoʊkɪŋ saʊn əz ɡɹeɪndəl ɹæpt ɪm ɪn wivz ʌv ɛɹ ən dʌɡ ɪndə hɪz maɪnd. hi stʌɾɝd, aɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ənfoʊkəst.

He cut off with a choking sound as Graendal wrapped him in weaves of Air and dug into his mind. He stuttered, eyes growing unfocused.

"aɪ æm paɪkɝ ɹæmʃələn," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə mɑnətoʊn. "aɪ hæv bɪn sɛn baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tə sik ən əlaɪəns wɪð ðə mɝtʃən fæmli ɹɪzaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɪs fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən. əz aɪm smɑɹɾɝ ən mɔɹ klɛvɝ ðən ælθɹ, hi nidz mi tə bɪld əlaɪənsəz fəɹ hɪm. hiz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli əfɹeɪɾ ə ðoʊz lɪvɪŋ ɪn ðɪs pæləs, wɪtʃ aɪ faɪn ɹɪdɪkjələs, sɪns ɪts dɪstən ən ənɪmpɔɹɾənt.

"I am Piqor Ramshalan," he said in a monotone. "I have been sent by the Dragon Reborn to seek an alliance with the merchant family residing in this fortification. As I am smarter and more clever than al'Thor, he needs me to build alliances for him. He is particularly afraid of those living in this palace, which I find ridiculous, since it is distant and unimportant.

"ɑbviəsli, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz ə wik mæn. aɪ bɪliv ðət baɪ ɡeɪnɪŋ ɪz kɑnfəɾəns, aɪ kən bi tʃoʊzən əz ðə nɛks kɪŋ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən. aɪ wɪʃ fəɹ jə tə meɪk ən əlaɪəns wɪð mi, nɑt wɪð hɪm, ən wɪl pɹɑməs jə feɪvɝz wʌns aɪm kɪŋ. aɪ di - "

"Obviously, the Dragon Reborn is a weak man. I believe that by gaining his confidence, I can be chosen as the next King of Arad Doman. I wish for you to make an alliance with me, not with him, and will promise you favors once I am king. I d - "

ɡɹeɪndəl weɪvd ə hæn ən i kʌɾ ɔf ɪn mɪdwɝd. ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, hɛɹz bɹɪsəlɪŋ əz ʃi ʃɪvɝd.

Graendal waved a hand and he cut off in midword. She folded her arms, hairs bristling as she shivered.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd faʊn hɝ.

The Dragon Reborn had found her.

hi hæd sɛn ə dɪstʃɹækʃən fəɹ hɝ.

He had sent a distraction for her.

hi θɔɾ i kəd mənɪpjəleɪt hɝ.

He thought he could manipulate her.

ʃi ɪnstənli woʊv ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə wʌn ə hɝ moʊst sɪkjʊɹ haɪɾɪŋ pleɪsəz. kul ɛɹ wɑftɪɾ ɪn fɹəm ən ɛɹiə ʌv ðə wɝld wɛɹ ɪt wɑz mɔɹnɪŋ, nɑɾ ɝli ivnɪŋ. bɛs tə bi kɛɹfəl. bɛs tə fli. ən jɛt . .

She instantly wove a gateway to one of her most secure hiding places. Cool air wafted in from an area of the world where it was morning, not early evening. Best to be careful. Best to flee. And yet . .

.

.

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi mʌs noʊ peɪn . . . hi mʌs noʊ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən . . . hi mʌs noʊ æŋɡwɪʃ. bɹɪŋ ðiz tə hɪm. jəl bi ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd.

She hesitated. He must know pain . . . he must know frustration . . . he must know anguish. Bring these to him. You will be rewarded.

ɝæŋɡɝ hæd flɛd fɹəm əɹ pleɪs əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, fulɪʃli əlaʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə bi sɛns tʃænəlɪŋ seɪɾɪn. ʃi stɪl bɔɹ pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ əɹ feɪljɝ. ɪf ɡɹeɪndəl lɛf naʊ - dɪskɑɹɾɪŋ ə tʃæns tə twɪst ælθɹ əbaʊt hɪmsɛlf - wəd ʃi bi sɪməlɝli pʌnɪʃt?

Aran'gar had fled from her place among Aes Sedai, foolishly allowing herself to be sensed channeling saidin. She still bore punishment for her failure. If Graendal left now - discarding a chance to twist al'Thor about himself - would she be similarly punished?

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" ɝæŋɡɝz vɔɪs æskt aʊtsaɪd. "lɛt mi θɹu, jə fulz. ɡɹeɪndəl? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?"

"What is this?" Aran'gar's voice asked outside. "Let me through, you fools. Graendal? What are you doing?"

ɡɹeɪndəl hɪst sɔfli, ðən kloʊz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ən kəmpoʊz hɝsɛlf. ʃi nɑɾəd fəɹ ɝæŋɡɝ tə bi əlaʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum. ðə laɪð wʊmən stɛpt ʌp tə ðə dɔɹweɪ, aɪɪŋ - ən əsɛsɪŋ -  ɹæmʃələn. ɡɹeɪndəl ʃʊdn əv sɛn ðə pɛts tə hɝ; ðə muv hæd laɪkli meɪɾ əɹ səspɪʃəs.

Graendal hissed softly, then closed the gateway and composed herself. She nodded for Aran'gar to be allowed into the room. The lithe woman stepped up to the doorway, eyeing - and assessing -  Ramshalan. Graendal shouldn't have sent the pets to her; the move had likely made her suspicious.

"ælθɹ əz faʊn mi," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd kɝtli. "hi sɛn ðɪs wʌn tə meɪk ən 'əlaɪəns' wɪð mi, bʌt dɪd nɑt tɛl ɪm u aɪ wɑz. ælθɹ laɪkli wɑns mi tə θɪŋk ðət ðɪs mæn stʌmbəld əpɑn mi æksədɛntəli."

"Al'Thor has found me," Graendal said curtly. "He sent this one to make an 'alliance' with me, but did not tell him who I was. Al'Thor likely wants me to think that this man stumbled upon me accidentally."

ɝæŋɡɝ pɝst əɹ lɪps. "soʊ jəl fli? ɹʌn fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪksaɪtmən əɡɛn?"

Aran'gar pursed her lips. "So you'll flee? Run from the center of excitement again?"

"ðɪs, fɹəm ju?"

"This, from you?"

"aɪ wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɛnəmiz. flaɪt wɑz maɪ oʊnli ɑpʃən." ɪt saʊndəd laɪk ə pɹæktəs laɪn.

"I was surrounded by enemies. Flight was my only option." It sounded like a practiced line.

wɝdz laɪk ðoʊz wɝ ə tʃælənʒ. ɝæŋɡɝ wəd sɝv hɝ. pɝhæps . . . "dʌz ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv jʊɹz noʊ kəmpʌlʃən?"

Words like those were a challenge. Aran'gar would serve her. Perhaps . . . "Does that Aes Sedai of yours know Compulsion?"

ɝæŋɡɝ ʃɹʌɡd. "ʃiz bɪn tʃɹeɪn ɪn ɪt. ʃiz pæsəbli skɪld."

Aran'gar shrugged. "She's been trained in it. She's passably skilled."

"fɛtʃ hɝ."

"Fetch her."

ɝæŋɡɝ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt nɑɾəd ɪn dɛfɝəns, dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ tə ɹʌn ði ɛɹən hɝsɛlf -  pɹɑbli tə ɡeɪn taɪm tə θɪŋk. ɡɹeɪndəl sɛn ə sɝvən fəɹ wʌn ə hɝ dʌv keɪdʒɪz. ðeɪ ɝaɪvd wɪð ðə bɝd bɪfɔɹ ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz bæk, ən ɡɹeɪndəl kɛɹfəli woʊv ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ - wʌns əɡɛn θɹɪlɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌʃ ə hoʊldɪŋ ɪt - ən kɹæftɪɾ ə kɑmplɛks wiv ə spɪɹət. kəd ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ tə də ðɪs? ɪt hæd bɪn soʊ lɔŋ.

Aran'gar raised an eyebrow, but nodded in deference, disappearing to run the errand herself -  probably to gain time to think. Graendal sent a servant for one of her dove cages. They arrived with the bird before Aran'gar was back, and Graendal carefully wove the True Power - once again thrilling in the rush of holding it - and crafted a complex weave of Spirit. Could she remember how to do this? It had been so long.

ʃi oʊvɝleɪd ðə wiv ɑn ðə bɝdz maɪnd. hɝ vɪʒən sim tə snæp. ɪn ə moʊmənt, ʃi kəd si tu ɪmədʒəz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ - ðə wɝld əz ʃi sɔ ɪɾ ən ə ʃæɾoʊd vɝʒən ʌv wʌt ðə bɝd sɔ. ɪf ʃi foʊkəst, ʃi kəd tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ.

She overlaid the weave on the bird's mind. Her vision seemed to snap. In a moment, she could see two images in front of her - the world as she saw it and a shadowed version of what the bird saw. If she focused, she could turn her attention to one or the other.

ɪt meɪɾ əɹ maɪn hɝt. ðə vɪʒən ʌv ə bɝd wɑz ɪntaɪɝli dɪfɹən fɹəm ðəɾ ʌv ə hjumən biɪŋ: ʃi kəd si ə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ fild, ən ðə kʌlɝz wɝ soʊ vɪvəɾ əz tə bi nɪɹli blaɪndɪŋ, bʌt ðə vju wɑz blɝi, ən ʃi hæd tʃɹʌbəl dʒʌdʒɪŋ dɪstəns.

It made her mind hurt. The vision of a bird was entirely different from that of a human being: She could see a much larger field, and the colors were so vivid as to be nearly blinding, but the view was blurry, and she had trouble judging distance.

ʃi tʌk ðə bɝdz saɪɾ ɪndə ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd. ə dʌv wəd bi ʌnəbtʃɹusɪv, bʌt juzɪŋ wʌn wɑz mɔɹ dɪfəkəl ðən ə ɹeɪvən əɹ ə ɹæt, ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn feɪvɝɾ aɪz. ðə wiv wɝk bɛɾɝ ɑn ðoʊz ðən ɪt dɪɾ ʌðɝ ænəməlz. ðoʊ, moʊs vɝmɪn ðət wɑtʃt fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd tə ɹipɔɹt bæk bɪfɔɹ i nu wʌt ðeɪd sin. waɪ ðət wɑz, ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən - ði ɪntʃɹəkəsiz ə ðə tʃɹu paʊɝz spɛʃəl wivz nɛvɝ hæd meɪd mʌtʃ sɛns tə hɝ. nɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ hæd tə eɪdʒɪnɝ, ət list.

She tucked the bird's sight into the back of her head. A dove would be unobtrusive, but using one was more difficult than a raven or a rat, the Dark One's own favored eyes. The weave worked better on those than it did other animals. Though, most vermin that watched for the Dark One had to report back before he knew what they'd seen. Why that was, she was not certain - the intricacies of the True Power's special weaves never had made much sense to her. Not as much as they had to Aginor, at least.

ɝæŋɡɝ ɹɪtɝnd wɪð əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli tɪmɪd ðiz deɪz. ʃi kɝtsid loʊ tə ɡɹeɪndəl, ðən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ə səbsɝviən pɑstʃɝ. ɡɹeɪndəl kɛɹfəli ɹimuvd əɹ kəmpʌlʃən fɹəm ɹæmʃə-læn, livɪŋ ɪm deɪzd ən dɪsɔɹiɛntɪd.

Aran'gar returned with her Aes Sedai, who was looking increasingly timid these days. She curtsied low to Graendal, then remained in a subservient posture. Graendal carefully removed her Compulsion from Ramsha-lan, leaving him dazed and disoriented.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə wɪʃ mi tə du, ɡɹeɪt wʌn?" dɛlænə æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɝæŋɡɝ ən ðən bæk ət ɡɹeɪndəl.

"What is it you wish me to do, Great One?" Delana asked, glancing at Arangar and then back at Graendal.

"kəmpʌlʃən," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "æz ɪntʃɹəkəɾ ən əz kɑmplɛks əz jə kən meɪk ɪt."

"Compulsion," Graendal said. "As intricate and as complex as you can make it."

"wʌt dʒju wɪʃ ɪt tə du, ɡɹeɪt leɪɾi?"

"What do you wish it to do, Great Lady?"

"liv ɪm eɪbəl tə æk laɪk hɪmsɛlf," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "bʌt ɹimuv ɔl mɛmɹi ʌv ɪvɛns hɪɹ.

"Leave him able to act like himself," Graendal said. "But remove all memory of events here.

ɹipleɪs əm wɪð ə mɛmɹi ʌv tɔkɪŋ tə ə mɝtʃən fæmli ən sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ əlaɪəns. æɾ ə fju ʌðɝ ɹændəm ɹɪkwaɪɹməns ɑn hɪm, wʌtɛvɝ əkɝz tə ju."

Replace them with a memory of talking to a merchant family and securing their alliance. Add a few other random requirements on him, whatever occurs to you."

dɛlænə fɹaʊnd, bʌt ʃi hæd lɝnd nɑt tə kwɛstʃən ðə tʃoʊzən. ɡɹeɪndəl foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ən tæpt wʌn fɪŋɡɝ əz ʃi wɑtʃt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk. ʃi fɛlt ɪnkɹisɪŋli nɝvəs. ælθɹ nu wɛɹ ʃi wɑz. wəɾ i ətæk? noʊ, hi wʊdn hɑɹm wɪmən. ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ feɪlɪŋ wɑz ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt wʌn. ɪt mɛnt ʃi hæd taɪm tə ɹɪspɑnd. dɪdnt ʃi?

Delana frowned, but she had learned not to question the Chosen. Graendal folded her arms and tapped one finger as she watched the Aes Sedai work. She felt increasingly nervous. Al'Thor knew where she was. Would he attack? No, he wouldn't harm women. That particular failing was an important one. It meant she had time to respond. Didn't she?

haʊ hæɾ i mænədʒ tə tʃɹeɪs əɹ tə ðɪs pæləs? ʃi hæd kʌvɝd hɝsɛlf pɝfəkli. ði oʊnli mɪnjənz ʃid lɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt wɝ ʌndɝ kəmpʌlʃən soʊ hɛvi ðəɾ ɪt wəd kɪl əm tə ɹimuv ɪt. kəɾ ɪt bi ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hi kɛpt wɪð ɪm - nɪneɪiv, ðə wʊmən ɡɪftəɾ ɪn hilɪŋ -  hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ʌndɝmaɪn ən ɹɛd ɡɹeɪndəlz wivz?

How had he managed to trace her to this palace? She had covered herself perfectly. The only minions she'd let out of her sight were under Compulsion so heavy that it would kill them to remove it. Could it be that the Aes Sedai he kept with him - Nynaeve, the woman gifted in Healing -  had been able to undermine and read Graendal's weaves?

ɡɹeɪndəl niɾəd taɪm, ən ʃi niɾəd tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌɾ ælθɹ nu. ɪf nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə hæd ðə skɪl niɾəd tə ɹid kəmpʊlʃənz, ðət wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. ɡɹeɪndəl niɾəd tə leɪ hɪm ə fɔls tʃɹeɪl, dɪleɪ hɪm - hɛns əɹ ɹɪkwaɪɹmən ðət dɛlænə kɹieɪɾ ə θɪk kəmpʌlʃən wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ pɹəvɪʒənz ɪn ɪt.

Graendal needed time, and she needed to discover what al'Thor knew. If Nynaeve al'Meara had the skill needed to read Compulsions, that was dangerous. Graendal needed to lay him a false trail, delay him - hence her requirement that Delana create a thick Compulsion with strange provisions in it.

bɹɪŋ ɪm æɡəni. ɡɹeɪndəl kəd də ðæt.

Bring him agony. Graendal could do that.

"ju nɛkst," ʃi sɛd tə ɝæŋɡɝ wʌns dɛlænə hæd fɪnɪʃt. "sʌmθɪŋ kɑnvəluɾəd. aɪ wɑn ælθɹ ən ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ tə faɪn ðə tʌtʃ ʌv ə mæn ɑn ðə maɪnd." ðət wəd kənfjuz əm fɝðɝ.

"You next," she said to Arangar once Delana had finished. "Something convoluted. I want al'Thor and his Aes Sedai to find the touch of a man on the mind." That would confuse them further.

ɝæŋɡɝ ʃɹʌɡd, bʌt dɪɾ əz æskt, leɪɪŋ daʊn ə θɪk ən kɑmplɛks kəmpʌlʃən ɑn ði ənfɔɹtʃənət ɹæmʃələnz maɪnd. hi wɑz sʌmwʌt pɹɪɾi. dɪɾ ælθɹ əsum ʃid wɑn ɪm fəɹ wʌn ə hɝ pɛts? dɪɾ i ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪnʌf ə biɪŋ luz θɝɪn tə noʊ ðəɾ əbaʊt hɝ? hɝ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn haʊ mʌtʃ ə hɪz oʊld laɪf i ɹɪmɛmbɝd wɝ kɑntʃɹədɪktɝi, bʌɾ i sim tə bi ɹɪkɔlɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ. ðət wɑz wʌt wɝid hɝ. luz θɝɪn cʊɾə tʃɹækt əɹ tə ðɪs pæləs, pɝhæps.

Arangar shrugged, but did as asked, laying down a thick and complex Compulsion on the unfortunate Ramshalan's mind. He was somewhat pretty. Did al'Thor assume she'd want him for one of her pets? Did he even remember enough of being Lews Therin to know that about her? Her reports on how much of his old life he remembered were contradictory, but he seemed to be recalling more and more. That was what worried her. Lews Therin could have tracked her to this palace, perhaps.

ʃid nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd ðəɾ ælθɹ wəd bi eɪbəl tə də ðə seɪm.

She'd never expected that al'Thor would be able to do the same.

ɝæŋɡɝ fɪnɪʃt.

Arangar finished.

"naʊ," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd, ɹilisɪŋ əɹ wivz ʌv ɛɹ ən spikɪŋ tə ɹæmʃələn, "ɹɪtɝn ən tɛl ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ə jəɹ səksɛs hɪɹ."

"Now," Graendal said, releasing her weaves of Air and speaking to Ramshalan, "return and tell the Dragon Reborn of your success here."

ɹæmʃələn blɪŋkt, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ . . . jɛs, maɪ leɪɾi. jɛs, aɪ bɪliv ðə taɪz wi meɪd tədeɪ wɪl bi ɪkstʃɹimli bɛnəfɪʃəl tə boʊθ ʌv ʌs." hi smaɪld. wik-maɪndəd ful. "pɝhæps wi ʃəd daɪn ən dʒɹɪŋk tə əɹ səksɛs, leɪɾi bæsin? ɪts bɪn ə wiɹiɪŋ tʃɹɪp tə si ju, ən aɪ - "

Ramshalan blinked, shaking his head. "I . . . Yes, my Lady. Yes, I believe the ties we made today will be extremely beneficial to both of us." He smiled. Weak-minded fool. "Perhaps we should dine and drink to our success, Lady Basene? It has been a wearying trip to see you, and I - "

"ɡoʊ," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd koʊldli.

"Go," Graendal said coldly.

"vɛɹi wɛl. jəl bi ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd wən aɪm kɪŋ!"

"Very well. You will be rewarded when I am king!"

hɝ ɡɑɹdz lɛɾ ɪm əweɪ, ən i bɪɡæn wɪslɪŋ wɪð ə sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd ɛɹ. ɡɹeɪndəl sæt daʊn ən kloʊzd əɹ aɪz; sɛvɹəl ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz stɛpt oʊvɝ tə ɡɑɹd hɝ, ðɛɹ buts sɑft ɑn ðə θɪk ɹʌɡ.

Her guards led him away, and he began whistling with a self-satisfied air. Graendal sat down and closed her eyes; several of her soldiers stepped over to guard her, their boots soft on the thick rug.

ʃi lʊk θɹu ðə dʌvz aɪz, əkʌstəmɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ɪts stʃɹeɪnʒ weɪ ʌv siɪŋ. əɾ əɹ ɔɹɾɝ, ə sɝvən pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp ən kæɹiɾ ɪt tə ə wɪndoʊ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum. ðə bɝd hɑpt ɑntu ðə wɪndaʊsəl. ɡɹeɪndəl ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə sɑf nʌdʒ tə ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd; ʃi wɑzn pɹæktəst ɪnʌf tə teɪk kəntʃɹoʊl kəmplitli. flaɪɪŋ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl ðən ɪt lʊkt.

She looked through the dove's eyes, accustoming herself to its strange way of seeing. At her order, a servant picked it up and carried it to a window in the hallway outside the room. The bird hopped onto the windowsill. Graendal gave it a soft nudge to go forward; she wasn't practiced enough to take control completely. Flying was far more difficult than it looked.

ðə dʌv flæpt aʊɾ ə ðə wɪndoʊ. ðə sʌn wɑz loʊɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə maʊntənz, aʊtlaɪnɪŋ əm ɪn æŋɡɹi ɹɛɾ ən ɔɹənʒ, ən ðə leɪk bɪloʊ fɛl ɪndə ə dip, ʃæɾoʊi blu-blæk. ðə vju wɑz θɹɪlɪŋ bʌt nɔʒieɪɾɪŋ əz ðə dʌv sɔɹɾ ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən lændəɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə taʊɝz.

The dove flapped out of the window. The sun was lowering behind the mountains, outlining them in angry red and orange, and the lake below fell into a deep, shadowy blue-black. The view was thrilling but nauseating as the dove soared up into the air and landed on one of the towers.

ɹæmʃələn ɪvɛntʃəwəli wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪts bɪloʊ. ɡɹeɪndəl nʌdʒ ðə dʌv ən ɪt lɛpt ɔf ðə taʊɝ, plʌnʒɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɡɹeɪndəl ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ ət ðə stʌmək-tʃɝnɪŋ dɪsɛnt, ðə pæləs stoʊnwɝks bɪkʌmɪŋ ə blɝ. ðə dʌv lɛvəld aʊɾ ən flæpt æftɝ ɹæmʃələn. hi sim tə bi ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, ðoʊ ʃi kəd meɪk aʊɾ oʊnli ɹuɾəmɛntɝi saʊnz θɹu ðə dʌvz ʌnfəmɪljɝ ɪɹhoʊlz.

Ramshalan eventually walked out of the gates below. Graendal nudged the dove and it leaped off the tower, plunging toward the ground. Graendal gritted her teeth at the stomach-churning descent, the palace stoneworks becoming a blur. The dove leveled out and flapped after Ramshalan. He seemed to be grumbling to himself, though she could make out only rudimentary sounds through the dove's unfamiliar earholes.

ʃi fɑloʊɾ ɪm fəɹ səm taɪm θɹu ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ wʊdz. ən aʊl wʊɾə bɪn bɛɾɝ, bʌt ʃi dɪdn əv wʌn kæptɪv. ʃi tʃaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðæt. ðə dʌv flu fɹəm bɹæntʃ tə bɹæntʃ. ðə fɔɹəs flɔɹ wɑz ə mɛsi tæŋɡəl ʌv ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ən fɔlən paɪn niɾəlz. ʃi faʊn ðət dɪstɪŋkli ənplɛzənt.

She followed him for some time through the darkening woods. An owl would have been better, but she didn't have one captive. She chided herself for that. The dove flew from branch to branch. The forest floor was a messy tangle of underbrush and fallen pine needles. She found that distinctly unpleasant.

ðəɹ wɑz laɪɾ ʌp əhɛd. ɪt wɑz feɪnt, bʌt ðə dʌvz aɪz kəɾ izəli pɪk aʊt laɪɾ ən ʃædoʊ, moʊʃən ən stɪlnəs. ʃi nʌdʒd ɪt tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt, livɪŋ ɹæmʃələn.

There was light up ahead. It was faint, but the dove's eyes could easily pick out light and shadow, motion and stillness. She nudged it to investigate, leaving Ramshalan.

ðə laɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə klɪɹ pætʃ, spɪlɪŋ fɔɹθ ə wɔɹm ɡloʊ.

The light was coming from a gateway in the middle of a clear patch, spilling forth a warm glow.

ðəɹ wɝ fɪɡjɝz stændɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪt. wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz ælθɹ.

There were figures standing before it. One of them was al'Thor.

ɡɹeɪndəl fɛlt ɪnstən pænɪk. hi wɑz hɪɹ. lʊkɪŋ daʊn oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪdʒ, təwɔɹd hɝ. dɑɹknəs wɪðɪn! ʃi hædnt noʊn fəɹ sɝɾən ɪf hid bi hɪɹ ɪn pɝsən, əɹ ɪf ɹæmʃələn wəd tʃɹævəl θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ɡɪv ɪz ɹipɔɹt. wʌt ɡeɪm wɑz ælθɹ pleɪɪŋ? ʃi lændəɾ əɹ dʌv ɑn ə bɹæntʃ. ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz kəmpleɪnɪŋ ən æskɪŋ ɡɹeɪndəl wʌt ʃi wɑz siɪŋ. ʃid sin ðə dʌv, ən wəd noʊ wʌt ɡɹeɪndəl wɑz ʌp tə.

Graendal felt instant panic. He was here. Looking down over the ridge, toward her. Darkness within! She hadn't known for certain if he'd be here in person, or if Ramshalan would travel through a gateway to give his report. What game was al'Thor playing? She landed her dove on a branch. Aran'gar was complaining and asking Graendal what she was seeing. She'd seen the dove, and would know what Graendal was up to.

ɡɹeɪndəl kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd hɑɹɾɝ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðə mæn u hæd wʌns bɪn luz θɝɪn tɛləmən. hi nu wɛɹ ʃi wɑz. hi hæd wʌns heɪɾəd əɹ dipli; haʊ mʌtʃ dɪɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝ? dɪɾ i ɹikɔl əɹ mɝɾɝ ə jənət?

Graendal concentrated harder. The Dragon Reborn, the man who had once been Lews Therin Telamon. He knew where she was. He had once hated her deeply; how much did he remember? Did he recall her murder of Yanet?

ælθɝz teɪm il bɹɔt ɹæmʃələn fɔɹwɝd, ən nɪneɪiv ɪnspɛktɪd hɪm. jɛs, ðət nɪneɪiv dɪd sim tə bi eɪbəl tə ɹid kəmpʌlʃən. ʃi nu wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ, ət list. ʃi wəɾ əv tə daɪ;

Al'Thors tame Aiel brought Ramshalan forward, and Nynaeve inspected him. Yes, that Nynaeve did seem to be able to read Compulsion. She knew what to look for, at least. She would have to die;

ælθɹ ɹɪlaɪɾ əpɑn hɝ; hɝ dɛθ wəd bɹɪŋ ɪm peɪn. ən æftɝ hɝ, ælθɝz dɑɹk-hɛɹd lʌvɝ.

al'Thor relied upon her; her death would bring him pain. And after her, al'Thors dark-haired lover.

ɡɹeɪndəl nʌdʒ ðə dʌv daʊn ɑntu ə loʊɝ bɹæntʃ. wʌt wəɾ ælθɹ du? ɡɹeɪndəlz ɪnstɪŋks sɛɾ i wʊdn dɛɹ muv, nɑɾ əntɪl i ənɹævəld əɹ plɑt. hi æktəd ðə seɪm naʊ əz i hæd dʊɹɪŋ əɹ eɪdʒ; hi laɪk tə plæn, tə spɛn taɪm bɪldɪŋ tə ə kɹɪʃɛndoʊ ʌv ən əsɔlt.

Graendal nudged the dove down onto a lower branch. What would al'Thor do? Graendal's instincts said he wouldn't dare move, not until he unraveled her plot. He acted the same now as he had during her Age; he liked to plan, to spend time building to a crescendo of an assault.

ʃi fɹaʊnd. wʌt wɑz i seɪɪŋ? ʃi stʃɹeɪnd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk sɛns ə ðə saʊnz. kɝs bɝdz ɪɹhoʊlz - ðə vɔɪsəz saʊndəd laɪk kɹoʊks. kæl-lændɝ? waɪ wɑz i tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt kælændɝ? ən ə bɑks . . .

She frowned. What was he saying? She strained, trying to make sense of the sounds. Cursed bird's earholes - the voices sounded like croaks. Cal-landor? Why was he talking about Callandor? And a box . . .

sʌmθɪŋ bɝst əlaɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænd. ði æksɛs ki. ɡɹeɪndəl ɡæspt. hid bɹɔt ðət wɪð hɪm?

Something burst alight in his hand. The access key. Graendal gasped. He'd brought that with him?

ɪt wɑz nɪɹli əz bæɾ əz bɑlfaɪɝ.

It was nearly as bad as balefire.

sʌɾənli ʃi ʌndɝstʊd. ʃid bɪn pleɪd.

Suddenly she understood. She'd been played.

koʊld, tɛɹəfaɪd, ʃi ɹilis ðə dʌv ən snæpt əɹ aɪz oʊpən. ʃi wɑz stɪl sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə smɔl, wɪndoʊləs ɹum, ɝæŋɡɝ linɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəd.

Cold, terrified, she released the dove and snapped her eyes open. She was still sitting in the small, windowless room, Aran'gar leaning beside the doorway with arms folded.

ælθɹ hæd sɛn ɹæmʃələn ɪn, ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪm tə bi kæptʃɝd, ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪm tə hæv kəmpʌlʃən pleɪst ɑn hɪm. ɹæmʃələnz oʊnli pɝpəs wɑz tə ɡɪv ælθɹ kɑnfɝmeɪʃən ðət ɡɹeɪndəl wɑz ɪn ðə taʊɝ.

Al'Thor had sent Ramshalan in, expecting him to be captured, expecting him to have Compulsion placed on him. Ramshalan's only purpose was to give al'Thor confirmation that Graendal was in the tower.

laɪt! haʊ klɛvɝ hiz bɪkʌm.

Light! How clever he's become.

ʃi ɹilis ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ ən ɛmbɹeɪs lɛs-wʌndɝfəl seɪaɪdɑɹ. kwɪkli! ʃi wɑz soʊ ənsɛɾəld ðəɾ əɹ ɛmbɹeɪs nɪɹli feɪld. ʃi wɑz swɛɾɪŋ.

She released the True Power and embraced less-wonderful saidar. Quickly! She was so unsettled that her embrace nearly failed. She was sweating.

ɡoʊ. ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ.

Go. She had to go.

ʃi oʊpən ə nu ɡeɪtweɪ. ɝæŋɡɝ tɝnd, stɛɹɪŋ θɹu ðə wɔlz ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ʌv ælθɹ.

She opened a new gateway. Aran'gar turned, staring through the walls in the direction of al'Thor.

"soʊ mʌtʃ paʊɝ! wʌɾ ɪz i duɪŋ?"

"So much power! What is he doing?"

ɝæŋɡɝ. ʃi ən dɛlænə hæd meɪd ðə wivz ə kəmpʌlʃən.

Aran'gar. She and Delana had made the weaves of Compulsion.

ælθɹ mʌs θɪŋk ɡɹeɪndəl dɛd. ɪf i dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə pleɪs ən ðoʊz kəmpʊlʃənz ɹɪmeɪnd, ælθɹ wəd noʊ ðət hid mɪst ən ðət ɡɹeɪndəl lɪvd.

Al'Thor must think Graendal dead. If he destroyed the place and those Compulsions remained, al'Thor would know that he'd missed and that Graendal lived.

ɡɹeɪndəl fɔɹm tu ʃilz ən slæmd əm ɪndə pleɪs, wʌn fəɹ ɝæŋɡɝ, wʌn fəɹ dɛlænə. ðə wɪmən ɡæspt. ɡɹeɪndəl taɪɾ ɔf ðə wivz ən baʊn ðə tu ɪn ɛɹ.

Graendal formed two shields and slammed them into place, one for Aran'gar, one for Delana. The women gasped. Graendal tied off the weaves and bound the two in Air.

"ɡɹeɪndəl?" ɝæŋɡɝ sɛd, vɔɪs pænɪkt. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə - "

"Graendal?" Aran'gar said, voice panicked. "What are you - "

ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ. ɡɹeɪndəl lɛp fəɹ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ɪt, tʌmbəlɪŋ ən ɹɪpɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛs ɑn ə bɹæntʃ. ə blaɪndɪŋ laɪt ɹoʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ. ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə dɪsmɪs ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən kɑt wʌn ɡlɪmps ə ðə hɔɹəfaɪɾ ɝæŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɪhaɪnd wɑz kənsumd ɪn bjuɾəfəl, pjʊɹ waɪtnəs.

It was coming. Graendal leaped for the gateway, rolling through it, tumbling and ripping her dress on a branch. A blinding light rose behind her. She struggled to dismiss the gateway, and caught one glimpse of the horrified Aran'gar before everything behind was consumed in beautiful, pure whiteness.

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃt, livɪŋ ɡɹeɪndəl ɪn dɑɹknəs.

The gateway vanished, leaving Graendal in darkness.

ʃi leɪ, hɑɹt biɾɪŋ əɾ ə tɛɹəbəl spid, nɪɹli blaɪndɪd baɪ ðə ɡlɛɹ. ʃid meɪd ðə kwɪkɪst ɡeɪtweɪ ʃi kʊd, wʌn ðət lɛɾ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. ʃi leɪ ɪn ðə dɝɾi ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ətɑp ə ɹɪdʒ bɪhaɪn ðə pæləs.

She lay, heart beating at a terrible speed, nearly blinded by the glare. She'd made the quickest gateway she could, one that led only a short distance away. She lay in the dirty underbrush atop a ridge behind the palace.

ə weɪv ə ɹɔŋɡnəs wɑʃt oʊvɝ hɝ, ə wɔɹpɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf ɹɪpəlɪŋ. ə bɑlɛskɹim, ɪt wɑz kɔld - ə moʊmənt wən kɹieɪʃən ɪtsɛlf haʊld ɪn peɪn.

A wave of wrongness washed over her, a warping in the air, the Pattern itself rippling. A balescream, it was called - a moment when creation itself howled in pain.

ʃi bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. bʌt ʃi hæd tə si. ʃi hæd tə noʊ. ʃi ɹoʊz tə hɝ fit, lɛft æŋkəl twɪstəd. ʃi hɑbəl tə ðə tʃɹilaɪn ən lʊk daʊn.

She breathed in and out, trembling. But she had to see. She had to know. She rose to her feet, left ankle twisted. She hobbled to the treeline and looked down.

nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ - ði ɪntaɪɝ pæləs - wɑz ɡɔn. bɝn aʊɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn. ʃi kʊdn si ælθɹ ɑn ɪz dɪstən ɹɪdʒ, bʌt ʃi nu wɛɹ i wɑz.

Natrin's Barrow - the entire palace - was gone. Burned out of the Pattern. She couldn't see al'Thor on his distant ridge, but she knew where he was.

"ju," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "ju hæv bɪkʌm fɑɹ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən aɪ əsumd."

"You," she growled. "You have become far more dangerous than I assumed."
