hʌnʒɹədz ə bjuɾəfəl mɛn ən wɪmən, ðə faɪnəst ʃid ɡæðɝd, ɡɔn. hɝ stʃɹɔŋhoʊld, dʌzənz ʌv aɪɾəmz ə paʊɝ, hɝ ɡɹeɪɾəst ælaɪ əmʌŋ ðə tʃoʊzən. ɡɔn. ðɪs wɑz ə dɪzæstɝ.

Hundreds of beautiful men and women, the finest she'd gathered, gone. Her stronghold, dozens of items of Power, her greatest ally among the Chosen. Gone. This was a disaster.

noʊ, ʃi θɔt. / laɪv. ʃiɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd hɪm, ɪf oʊnli baɪ ə fju moʊməns. naʊ hi wəd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz dɛd.

No, she thought. / live. She'd anticipated him, if only by a few moments. Now he would think she was dead.

ʃi wɑz sʌɾənli ðə seɪfəst ʃid bɪn sɪns ɪskeɪpɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. ɪksɛpt, ʌv kɔɹs, ðət ʃid dʒʌs kɑz ðə dɛθ ʌv wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wəd nɑt bi plizd.

She was suddenly the safest she'd been since escaping the Dark One's prison. Except, of course, that she'd just caused the death of one of the Chosen. The Great Lord would not be pleased.

ʃi lɪmpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪdʒ, ɔlɹɛɾi plænɪŋ əɹ nɛks muv. ðɪs wəɾ əv tə bi hændəl vɛɹi, vɛɹi kɛɹfəli.

She limped away from the ridge, already planning her next move. This would have to be handled very, very carefully.

ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, jæŋkt ɪz buɾɪd fʊt fɹi ʌv ði æŋkəl-dip mʌd wɪð ə slɝpɪŋ saʊnd. baɪtmz bʌzd ɪn ðə mʌɡi ɛɹ. ðə stɛntʃ ə mʌɾ ən stæɡnənt wɔɾɝ θɹɛɾənd tə ɡæɡ hɪm wɪð itʃ bɹɛθ əz i lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs tə dʒɹaɪɝ ɡɹaʊn ɑn ðə pæθ. bɪhaɪn ɪm tʃɹʌdʒd ə lɔŋ, twɪstɪŋ kɑləm fɔɹ mɛn waɪd, itʃ wʌn əz mʌɾid, swɛɾi ən wɪɹi əz i wɑz.

Galad Damodred, Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light, yanked his booted foot free of the ankle-deep mud with a slurping sound. Bitemes buzzed in the muggy air. The stench of mud and stagnant water threatened to gag him with each breath as he led his horse to drier ground on the path. Behind him trudged a long, twisting column four men wide, each one as muddied, sweaty and weary as he was.

ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɡildən ən ɔltɑɹə, ɪn ə swɑmpi wɛtlænd wɛɹ ði oʊks ən spɪswʊdz hæd ɡɪvən weɪ tə lɔɹəlz ən spaɪɾɝi saɪpɹəs, ðɛɹ nɑɹld ɹuts spɹɛd laɪk spɪnli fɪŋɡɝz. ðə stɪŋkɪŋ ɛɹ wɑz hɑt - dɪspaɪt ðə ʃeɪɾ ən klaʊd kʌvɝ - ən θɪk. ɪt wɑz laɪk bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ə faʊl sup. ɡɑləd stim bɪniθ ɪz bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən meɪl, hɪz kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, hɪz skɪn ɪtʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɡɹaɪm ən sɔlti swɛt.

They were on the border of Ghealdan and Altara, in a swampy wetland where the oaks and spicewoods had given way to laurels and spidery cypress, their gnarled roots spread like spindly fingers. The stinking air was hot - despite the shade and cloud cover - and thick. It was like breathing in a foul soup. Galad steamed beneath his breastplate and mail, his conical helmet hanging from his saddle, his skin itching from the grime and salty sweat.

mɪzɝəbəl ðoʊ ɪt wɑz, ðɪs ɹut wɑz ðə bɛst weɪ. əsunɑwə wəd nɑɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾ ɪt. ɡɑləd waɪpt ɪz bɹaʊ wɪð ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn ən tʃɹaɪd tə wɔk wɪð hɛd haɪ fəɹ ðə bɛnəfɪɾ ə ðoʊz u fɑloʊd hɪm. sɛvən θaʊzən mɛn, tʃɪlʒɹən u hæd tʃoʊzən ɪm ɹæðɝ ðən ðə sintʃæn ɪnveɪɾɝz.

Miserable though it was, this route was the best way. Asunawa would not anticipate it. Galad wiped his brow with the back of his hand and tried to walk with head high for the benefit of those who followed him. Seven thousand men, Children who had chosen him rather than the Seanchan invaders.

dʌl ɡɹin mɔs hʌŋ fɹəm ðə bɹæntʃəz, dʒɹupɪŋ laɪk ʃɹɛdz ə flɛʃ fɹəm ɹɑɾɪŋ kɔɹpsəz. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ðə sɪkli ɡɹeɪz ən ɡɹinz wɝ ɹɪliv baɪ ə bɹaɪt bɝst ə taɪni pɪŋk əɹ vaɪəlɪt flaʊɝz klʌstɝɪŋ ɝaʊn tʃɹɪklɪŋ stʃɹimz. ðɛɹ sʌɾən kʌlɝ wɑz ʌnɪkspɛktɪd, əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd spɹɪŋkəl dʒɹɑps ə peɪn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Dull green moss hung from the branches, drooping like shreds of flesh from rotting corpses. Here and there the sickly grays and greens were relieved by a bright burst of tiny pink or violet flowers clustering around trickling streams. Their sudden color was unexpected, as if someone had sprinkled drops of paint on the ground.

ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ tə faɪn bjuɾi ɪn ðɪs pleɪs. kəɾ i faɪn ðə laɪɾ ɪn ɪz oʊn sɪtʃueɪʃən əz wɛl? hi fɪɹɾ ɪt wəd nɑt bi soʊ izi.

It was strange to find beauty in this place. Could he find the Light in his own situation as well? He feared it would not be so easy.

hi tʌɡd staʊt fɔɹwɝd. hi kəd hɪɹ wɝid kɑnvɝseɪʃənz fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪd baɪ ði əkeɪʒənəl kɝs. ðɪs pleɪs, wɪð ɪts stɛntʃ ən baɪɾɪŋ ɪnsɛks, wəd tʃɹaɪ ðə bɛst ə mɛn. ðoʊz u fɑloʊd ɡɑləd wɝ ənnɝv baɪ ðə pleɪs ðə wɝld wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ. ə wɝld wɛɹ ðə skaɪ wɑz kɑnstənli klaʊɾəd blæk, wɛɹ ɡʊd mɛn daɪd tə stʃɹeɪnʒ twɪstɪŋz ə ðə pæɾɝn, ən wɛɹ vɑldə  - ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ bɪfɔɹ ɡɑləd -  hæd tɝn aʊt tə bi ə mɝɾɝɝ ən ə ɹeɪpɪst.

He tugged Stout forward. He could hear worried conversations from behind, punctuated by the occasional curse. This place, with its stench and biting insects, would try the best of men. Those who followed Galad were unnerved by the place the world was becoming. A world where the sky was constantly clouded black, where good men died to strange twistings of the Pattern, and where Valda  - the Lord Captain Commander before Galad -  had turned out to be a murderer and a rapist.

ɡɑləd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ðə læs bæɾəl wəd sun kʌm.

Galad shook his head. The Last Battle would soon come.

ə klɪŋkɪŋ ə tʃeɪn meɪl ənaʊnst sʌmwʌn muvɪŋ ʌp ðə laɪn. ɡɑləd ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz deɪn bɔɹnhəld ɝaɪvd, səluɾəd, ən fɛl ɪndə pleɪs bɪsaɪd hɪm. "dəmədʒɹd," deɪn sɛd sɔfli, ðɛɹ buts skwɪʃɪŋ ɪn mʌd, "pɝhæps wi ʃəd tɝn bæk."

A clinking of chain mail announced someone moving up the line. Galad glanced over his shoulder as Dain Bornhald arrived, saluted, and fell into place beside him. "Damodred," Dain said softly, their boots squishing in mud, "perhaps we should turn back."

"bækwɝd lidz oʊnli tə ðə pæst," ɡɑləd sɛd, skænɪŋ ðə pæθweɪ əhɛd. "aɪ hæv θɔɾ əbaʊt ðɪs mʌtʃ, tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld. ðɪs skaɪ, ðə weɪstɪŋ ə ðə lænd, ðə weɪ ðə dɛd wɔk . . . ðəɹ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ taɪm tə faɪn ælaɪz ən faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. wi mʌs mɑɹtʃ tə ðə læs bæɾəl."

"Backward leads only to the past," Galad said, scanning the pathway ahead. "I have thought about this much, Child Bornhald. This sky, the wasting of the land, the way the dead walk . . . There is no longer time to find allies and fight against the Seanchan. We must march to the Last Battle."

"bʌt ðɪs swɑmp," bɔɹnhəl sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saɪɾ əz ə lɑɹdʒ sɝpən slɪd θɹu ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ. "aʊɝ mæps seɪ wi ʃʊɾə bɪn aʊɾ ʌv ɪt baɪ naʊ."

"But this swamp," Bornhald said, glancing to the side as a large serpent slid through the underbrush. "Our maps say we should have been out of it by now."

"ðɛn ʃʊɹli wəɹ nɪɹ ði ɛdʒ."

"Then surely we are near the edge."

"pɝhæps," deɪn sɛd, ə tʃɹeɪl ə swɛt ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bɹaʊ daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz lin feɪs, wɪtʃ twɪtʃt. fɔɹtʃənətli, hid ɹʌn aʊɾ ə bɹændi ə fju deɪz bæk. "ənlɛs ðə mæp ɪz ɪn ɛɹɝ."

"Perhaps," Dain said, a trail of sweat running from his brow down the side of his lean face, which twitched. Fortunately, he'd run out of brandy a few days back. "Unless the map is in error."

ɡɑləd dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd. wʌns-ɡʊd mæps wɝ pɹuvɪŋ fɔlti ðiz deɪz. oʊpən filz wəd tɝn tə bɹoʊkən hɪlz, vɪlədʒəz wəd vænɪʃ, pæstʃɝz wəd bi ɛɹəbəl wʌn deɪ, ðən sʌɾənli oʊvɝɡɹoʊn wɪð vaɪnz ən fʌŋɡəs. ðə swɑmp kəɾ ɪndiɾ əv spɹɛd.

Galad didn't respond. Once-good maps were proving faulty these days. Open fields would turn to broken hills, villages would vanish, pastures would be arable one day, then suddenly overgrown with vines and fungus. The swamp could indeed have spread.

"ðə mɛn ɑɹ ɪɡzɔstəd," bɔɹnhəl sɛd. "ðeɪɹ ɡʊd mɛn - jə noʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ. bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə kəmpleɪn." hi wɪnst, əz ɪf æntɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ ə ɹɛpɹəmæn fɹəm ɡɑləd.

"The men are exhausted," Bornhald said. "They're good men - you know they are. But they are starting to complain." He winced, as if anticipating a reprimand from Galad.

pɝhæps wʌns i wʊɾə ɡɪvən wʌn. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ʃəd bɛɹ ðɛɹ əflɪkʃənz wɪð pɹaɪd.

Perhaps once he would have given one. The Children should bear their afflictions with pride.

haʊɛvɝ, mɛmɹiz ə lɛsənz mɔɹɡeɪs hæd tɔt -  lɛsənz i hædn ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪn ɪz juθ -  wɝ næɡɪŋ ət hɪm. lɛd baɪ ɪɡzæmpəl. ɹikwaɪɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ, bʌt fɝst ʃoʊ ɪt.

However, memories of lessons Morgase had taught -  lessons he hadn't understood in his youth -  were nagging at him. Lead by example. Require strength, but first show it.

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. ðeɪ wɝ nɪɹɪŋ ə dʒɹaɪ klɪɹɪŋ. "ɡæðɝ ðə mɛn. əl spik tə ðoʊz ət ðə fɹʌnt. hæv maɪ wɝdz ɹəkɔɹɾəd, ðən pæs tə ðoʊz bɪhaɪnd."

Galad nodded. They were nearing a dry clearing. "Gather the men. I will speak to those at the front. Have my words recorded, then passed to those behind."

bɔɹnhəld lʊk pɝplɛkst, bʌt dɪɾ əz kəmændəd. ɡɑləd stɛpt ɔf tə ðə saɪd, klaɪmɪŋ ʌp ə smɔl hɪl. hi pleɪst ɪz hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ɪz mɛn əz ðə kʌmpəniz ət ðə fɹʌnt ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊnd. ðeɪ stʊd wɪð slaʊtʃt pɑstʃɝz, lɛɡz mʌɾid. hænz fleɪld ət baɪtmz əɹ skɹætʃt ət kɑlɝz.

Bornhald looked perplexed, but did as commanded. Galad stepped off to the side, climbing up a small hill. He placed his hand on the hilt of his sword, inspecting his men as the companies at the front gathered around. They stood with slouched postures, legs muddied. Hands flailed at bitemes or scratched at collars.

"wi ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt," ɡɑləɾ ənaʊnst, wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɡæðɝd. "ðiz ɑɹ ðə dɑɹkəs deɪz ə mɛn. deɪz wən hoʊp ɪz wik, deɪz wən dɛθ ɹeɪnz. bʌɾ ɪts ɑn ðə dipəs naɪts wən laɪɾ ɪz moʊst ɡlɔɹiəs. dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ, ə bɹɪljən bikən kən əpɪɹ wik. bʌt wən ɔl ʌðɝ laɪts feɪl, ɪɾəl ɡaɪd!

"We are Children of the Light," Galad announced, once they were gathered. "These are the darkest days of men. Days when hope is weak, days when death reigns. But it is on the deepest nights when light is most glorious. During the day, a brilliant beacon can appear weak. But when all other lights fail, it will guide!

"wi ɑɹ ðət bikən. ðɪs maɪɹ ɪz ən əflɪkʃən. bʌt wəɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, ən əɹ əflɪkʃənz ɑɹ əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ. wəɹ hʌntəd baɪ ðoʊz u ʃəd lʌv ʌs, ən ʌðɝ pæθweɪz lɛd tə əɹ ɡɹeɪvz. ən soʊ wɪl ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd. fəɹ ðoʊz wi mʌs pɹətɛkt, fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl, fəɹ ðə laɪt!

"We are that beacon. This mire is an affliction. But we are the Children of the Light, and our afflictions are our strength. We are hunted by those who should love us, and other pathways lead to our graves. And so we will go forward. For those we must protect, for the Last Battle, for the Light!

"wɛɹ ɪz ðə vɪktɝi ʌv ðɪs swɑmp? aɪ ɹəfjuz tə fil ɪts baɪt, fəɹ aɪm pɹaʊd. pɹaʊd tə lɪv ɪn ðiz deɪz, pɹaʊd tə bi pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌɾ ɪz tə kʌm. ɔl ðə laɪvz ðət keɪm bɪfɔɹ əs ɪn ðɪs eɪdʒ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə əɹ deɪ, ðə deɪ wən mɛn wɪl bi tɛstəd. lɛɾ ʌðɝz bɪmoʊn ðɛɹ feɪt. lɛɾ ʌðɝz kɹaɪ ən weɪl. wɪl nɑt, fəɹ wɪl feɪs ðɪs tɛst wɪð hɛdz hɛl haɪ. ən wɪl lɛɾ ɪt pɹuv əs stʃɹɔŋ!"

"Where is the victory of this swamp? I refuse to feel its bite, for I am proud. Proud to live in these days, proud to be part of what is to come. All the lives that came before us in this Age looked forward to our day, the day when men will be tested. Let others bemoan their fate. Let others cry and wail. We will not, for we will face this test with heads held high. And we will let it prove us strong!"

nɑɾ ə lɔŋ spitʃ; hi dɪd nɑt wɪʃ tə ɪkstɛn ðɛɹ taɪm ɪn ðə swɑmp oʊvɝli mʌtʃ. stɪl, ɪt sim tə də ɪts duɾi. ðə mɛnz bæks stʃɹeɪɾənd, ən ðeɪ nɑɾəd. mɛn u hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən tə də soʊ ɹoʊt daʊn ðə wɝdz, ən muv bæk tə ɹiɾ əm tə ðoʊz u hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə hɪɹ.

Not a long speech; he did not wish to extend their time in the swamp overly much. Still, it seemed to do its duty. The men's backs straightened, and they nodded. Men who had been chosen to do so wrote down the words, and moved back to read them to those who had not been able to hear.

wən ðə tʃɹup kəntɪnjud fɔɹwɝd, ðə mɛnz fʊtstɛps noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dʒɹæɡd, ðɛɹ pɑstʃɝz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ slʌmpt. ɡɑləd ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɪz hɪlsaɪd, teɪkɪŋ ə fju ɹɪpɔɹts, lɛɾɪŋ ðə mɛn si hɪm əz ðeɪ pæst.

When the troop continued forward, the men's footsteps no longer dragged, their postures were no longer slumped. Galad remained on his hillside, taking a few reports, letting the men see him as they passed.

wən ðə læst ə ðə sɛvən θaʊzən hæd ɡɔn baɪ, ɡɑləd noʊɾəd ə smɔl ɡɹup weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl. tʃaɪl jɹət baɪɑɝ stʊd wɪð ðɛm, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət ɡɑləd, sʌŋkən aɪz əlaɪt wɪð zil. hi wɑz ɡɔnt, wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ feɪs.

When the last of the seven thousand had gone by, Galad noted a small group waiting at the base of the hill. Child Jaret Byar stood with them, looking up at Galad, sunken eyes alight with zeal. He was gaunt, with a narrow face.

"tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ," ɡɑləd sɛd, wɔkɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə hɪlsaɪd.

"Child Byar," Galad said, walking down from the hillside.

"ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd spitʃ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," baɪɑɝ sɛd fɝvənli. "ðə læs bæɾəl. jɛs, ɪts taɪm tə ɡoʊ tə ɪt."

"It was a good speech, my Lord Captain Commander," Byar said fervently. "The Last Battle. Yes, it is time to go to it."

"ɪɾ ɪz əɹ bɝɾən," ɡɑləd sɛd. "æn əɹ duɾi."

"It is our burden," Galad said. "And our duty."

"wi wɪl ɹaɪd nɔɹθwɝd," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "mɛn wɪl kʌm tə ʌs, ən wɪl ɡɹoʊ. ən ɪnɔɹməs fɔɹs ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, tɛnz ə θaʊzənz. hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz. wɪl wɑʃ oʊvɝ ðə lænd. meɪbi wɪl əv ɪnʌf mɛn tə kæs daʊn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ðə wɪtʃəz, ɹæðɝ ðən niɾɪŋ tə əlaɪ wɪð ðɛm."

"We will ride northward," Byar said. "Men will come to us, and we will grow. An enormous force of the Children, tens of thousands. Hundreds of thousands. We will wash over the land. Maybe we will have enough men to cast down the White Tower and the witches, rather than needing to ally with them."

ɡɑləd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wi wɪl nid ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. ðə ʃædoʊ wɪl əv dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz, mɹdʒɹɑl, fɔɹseɪkən"

Galad shook his head. "We will need the Aes Sedai, Child Byar. The Shadow will have Dreadlords, Myrddraal, Forsaken"

"jɛs, aɪ səpoʊz." baɪɑɝ simd ɹɪlʌktənt. wɛl, hid simd ɹɪlʌktən əbaʊt ði aɪdiə bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ i hæɾ əɡɹid tə ɪt.

"Yes, I suppose." Byar seemed reluctant. Well, he'd seemed reluctant about the idea before, but he had agreed to it.

"aʊɝ ɹoʊɾ ɪz dɪfəkəlt, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ, bʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɪl bi liɾɝz ət ðə læs bæɾəl."

"Our road is difficult, Child Byar, but the Children of the Light will be leaders at the Last Battle."

vɑldəz mɪsdidz hæd tɑɹnɪʃt ði ɪntaɪɝ ɔɹɾɝ. mɔɹ ðən ðæt, ɡɑləd wɑz ɪnkɹisɪŋli kənvɪns ðəɾ əsunɑwə hæd pleɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɹoʊl ɪn ðə mɪstʃɹitmən ən dɛθ ə hɪz stɛpmʌðɝ. ðət mɛn ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ hɪmsɛlf wɑz kɝʌpt.

Valda's misdeeds had tarnished the entire order. More than that, Galad was increasingly convinced that Asunawa had played a large role in the mistreatment and death of his stepmother. That meant the High Inquisitor himself was corrupt.

duɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt wɑz ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ ɪn laɪf. ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɛni sækɹəfaɪs. ət ðɪs taɪm, ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə də wɑz fli. ɡɑləd kəd nɑt feɪs əsunɑwə; ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ wɑz bæk baɪ ðə sintʃæn. bɪsaɪdz, ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Doing what was right was the most important thing in life. It required any sacrifice. At this time, the right thing to do was flee. Galad could not face Asunawa; the High Inquisitor was backed by the Seanchan. Besides, the Last Battle was more important.

ɡɑləd stɛp swɪfli, wɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə mʌk bæk təwɔɹd ðə fɹʌn ə ðə laɪn ə tʃɪlʒɹən.

Galad stepped swiftly, walking through the muck back toward the front of the line of Children.

ðeɪ tʃɹævəld laɪt, wɪð fju pæk ænəməlz, ən ɪz mɛn wɔɹ ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ - ðɛɹ maʊns wɝ leɪɾən wɪð fuɾ ən səplaɪz.

They traveled light, with few pack animals, and his men wore their armor - their mounts were laden with food and supplies.

ət ðə fɹʌnt, ɡɑləd faʊn tʃɹɑm spikɪŋ wɪð ə fju mɛn u wɔɹ lɛðɝz ən bɹaʊn kloʊks, nɑt waɪt tɑbɝdz ən stil kæps. ðɛɹ skaʊts. tʃɹɑm nɑɾəd tə hɪm ɪn ɹɪspɛkt; ðə lɔɹd kæptən wɑz wʌn ʌv ɡɑlədz moʊs tʃɹʌstɪd mɛn. "skaʊts seɪ ðɛɹz ə smɔl ɪʃu əhɛd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," tʃɹɑm sɛd.

At the front, Galad found Trom speaking with a few men who wore leathers and brown cloaks, not white tabards and steel caps. Their scouts. Trom nodded to him in respect; the Lord Captain was one of Galad's most trusted men. "Scouts say there's a small issue ahead, my Lord Captain Commander," Trom said.

"wʌɾ ɪʃu?"

"What issue?"

"ɪt wəd bi bɛs tə ʃoʊ ɪt tə jə dɝɛkli, sɝ," sɛd tʃaɪl bɑɹlɪt, ðə liɾɝ ə ðə skaʊts.

"It would be best to show it to you directly, sir," said Child Barlett, the leader of the scouts.

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd ɪm fɔɹwɝd. əhɛd, ðə swɑmpi fɔɹəst sim tə bi θɪnɪŋ. θæŋk ðə laɪt -  dɪd ðət min ðeɪ wɝ nɪɹli fɹi?

Galad nodded him forward. Ahead, the swampy forest seemed to be thinning. Thank the Light -  did that mean they were nearly free?

noʊ. əz ɡɑləɾ ɝaɪvd, hi faʊn sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ skaʊts lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ əɾ ə dɛd fɔɹəst. moʊs tʃɹiz ɪn ðə swɑmp bɔɹ livz, ðoʊ sɪkli wʌnz, bʌt ðoʊz əhɛd wɝ skɛləɾəl ən æʃən, əz ɪf bɝnd. ðəɹ wɑz səm kaɪndə sɪkli waɪt laɪkən əɹ mɔs ɡɹoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ðə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋks lʊkt ɪmeɪʃieɪɾɪd.

No. As Galad arrived, he found several other scouts looking out at a dead forest. Most trees in the swamp bore leaves, though sickly ones, but those ahead were skeletal and ashen, as if burned. There was some kind of sickly white lichen or moss growing over everything. The tree trunks looked emaciated.

wɔɾɝ flʌɾəd ðɪs ɛɹiə, ə waɪd bʌt ʃæloʊ ɹɪvɝ wɪð ə vɛɹi sloʊ kɝənt. ɪt hæd swɑloʊd ðə beɪsəz ə mɛni ʌv ðə tʃɹiz, ən fɔlən tʃɹi lɪmz bɹoʊk ðə dɝɾi bɹaʊn wɔɾɝ laɪk ɑɹmz ɹitʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ.

Water flooded this area, a wide but shallow river with a very slow current. It had swallowed the bases of many of the trees, and fallen tree limbs broke the dirty brown water like arms reaching toward the sky.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ kɔɹpsəz, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," wʌn ə ðə skaʊts sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ.

"There are corpses, my Lord Captain Commander," one of the scouts said, gesturing upriver.

"floʊɾɪŋ daʊn. lʊks laɪk ðə ɹɛmnəns ʌv ə dɪstən bæɾəl."

"Floating down. Looks like the remnants of a distant battle."

"ɪz ðɪs ɹɪvɝ ɑn əɹ mæps?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

"Is this river on our maps?" Galad asked.

wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðə skaʊts ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz.

One by one, the scouts shook their heads.

ɡɑləd sɛɾ ɪz dʒɔ. "kæn ðɪs bi fɔɹɾɪd?"

Galad set his jaw. "Can this be forded?"

"ɪts ʃæloʊ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," tʃaɪl bɑɹlɪt sɛd. "bʌt wɪl əv tə wɑtʃ fəɹ hɪɾən dɛpθs."

"It's shallow, my Lord Captain Commander," Child Barlett said. "But we'll have to watch for hidden depths."

ɡɑləd ɹitʃt aʊt tə ə tʃɹi bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ən bɹoʊk fɹi ə lɔŋ bɹæntʃ, ðə wʊd snæpɪŋ laʊdli. "aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ fɝst. hæv ðə mɛn ɹimuv ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ən kloʊks."

Galad reached out to a tree beside him and broke free a long branch, the wood snapping loudly. "I will go first. Have the men remove their armor and cloaks."

ði ɔɹɾɝz wɛn daʊn ðə laɪn, ən ɡɑləd tʊk ɔf ɪz ɑɹmɝ ən ɹæpt ɪɾ ɪn ɪz kloʊk, ðən taɪɾ ɪt tə hɪz bæk. hi haɪkt ʌp ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz əz fɑɹ əz i kʊd, ðən stɛp daʊn ðə dʒɛntəl bæŋk ən plaʊd fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ðə mɝki wɔɾɝ. ðə ʃɑɹpli koʊl spɹɪŋ ɹʌnɔf meɪɾ ɪm tɛns. hɪz buts sæŋk ɪntʃəz ɪndə ðə sændi bɑɾəm, fɪlɪŋ wɪð wɔɾɝ, stɝɪŋ ʌp swɝlz ə mʌd. staʊt meɪɾ ə laʊɾɝ splæʃ əz i stɛpt ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ bɪhaɪnd.

The orders went down the line, and Galad took off his armor and wrapped it in his cloak, then tied it to his back. He hiked up his trousers as far as he could, then stepped down the gentle bank and plowed forward into the murky water. The sharply cold spring runoff made him tense. His boots sank inches into the sandy bottom, filling with water, stirring up swirls of mud. Stout made a louder splash as he stepped into the water behind.

ɪt wɑzn tu dɪfəkəl tə wɔk ɪn; ðə wɔɾɝ oʊnli keɪm ʌp tə hɪz niz. hi juzd ɪz stɪk tə faɪn ðə bɛs fʊɾɪŋ. ðoʊz skɛləɾəl, daɪɪŋ tʃɹiz wɝ ənɝvɪŋ. ðeɪ dɪdn sim tə bi ɹɑɾɪŋ, ən naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz kloʊsɝ, hi kəd bɛɾɝ si ði æʃ-ɡɹeɪ fʌz əmʌŋ ðə laɪkən ðət koʊɾəd ðɛɹ tʃɹʌŋks ən bɹæntʃəz.

It wasn't too difficult to walk in; the water only came up to his knees. He used his stick to find the best footing. Those skeletal, dying trees were unnerving. They didn't seem to be rotting, and now that he was closer, he could better see the ash-gray fuzz among the lichen that coated their trunks and branches.

ðə tʃɪlʒɹən bɪhaɪn splæʃt laʊdli əz mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ðɛm ɛntɝd ðə waɪd stʃɹim. nɪɹbaɪ, bʌlbəs fɔɹmz floʊɾəd daʊn ðə ɹɪvɝ tə kætʃ əpɑn ɹɑks. səm wɝ ðə kɔɹpsəz ə mɛn, bʌt mɛni wɝ lɑɹdʒɝ. mjulz, hi ɹilaɪzd, kætʃɪŋ ə bɛɾɝ lʊk əɾ ə snaʊt. dʌzənz ə ðɛm. ðeɪd bɪn dɛd fəɹ səm taɪm, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ðə bloʊt.

The Children behind splashed loudly as more and more of them entered the wide stream. Nearby, bulbous forms floated down the river to catch upon rocks. Some were the corpses of men, but many were larger. Mules, he realized, catching a better look at a snout. Dozens of them. They'd been dead for some time, judging by the bloat.

laɪkli ə vɪlədʒ ʌpstʃɹim hæd bɪn ətæk fəɹ ɪts fud. ðɪs wɑzn ðə fɝst ɡɹup ə dɛd ðeɪd faʊnd.

Likely a village upstream had been attacked for its food. This wasn't the first group of dead they'd found.

hi ɹitʃt ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðən klaɪmd aʊt. əz i ənɹoʊld ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝ lɛɡz ən dɑn ɪz ɑɹmɝ ən kloʊk, hi fɛlt ɪz ʃoʊldɝ eɪkɪŋ fɹəm ðə bloʊz vɑldə hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. hɪz θaɪ stɪl stʌŋ, tu.

He reached the other side of the river, then climbed out. As he unrolled his trouser legs and donned his armor and cloak, he felt his shoulder aching from the blows Valda had given him. His thigh still stung, too.

hi tɝn ən kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə ɡeɪm tʃɹeɪl nɔɹθwɝd, liɾɪŋ ðə weɪ əz ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ɹitʃt ðə bæŋk. hi lɔŋ tə ɹaɪd staʊt, bʌɾ i dɛɹd nɑt. ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz stɪl dæmp, ənivən, ən pɑkt wɪð hɪɾən sɪŋkhoʊlz. ɪf i ɹoʊd, hi kəɾ izəli kɑst staʊɾ ə bɹoʊkən lɛɡ ən hɪmsɛlf ə bɹoʊkən kɹaʊn.

He turned and continued down the game trail northward, leading the way as other Children reached the bank. He longed to ride Stout, but he dared not. Though they were out of the river, the ground was still damp, uneven, and pocked with hidden sinkholes. If he rode, he could easily cost Stout a broken leg and himself a broken crown.

soʊ hi ən ɪz mɛn wɔkt, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðoʊz ɡɹeɪ tʃɹiz, swɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪzɝəbəl hit. hi lɔŋ fəɹ ə ɡʊd bæθ.

So he and his men walked, surrounded by those gray trees, sweating in the miserable heat. He longed for a good bath.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, tʃɹɑm dʒɑɡd ʌp ðə laɪn tə hɪm. "ɔl mɛn ɑɹ əkɹɔs seɪfli." hi tʃɛk ðə skaɪ.

Eventually, Trom jogged up the line to him. "All men are across safely." He checked the sky.

"bɝn ðoʊz klaʊdz. aɪ kən nɛvɝ tɛl wʌt taɪm ɪɾ ɪz."

"Burn those clouds. I can never tell what time it is."

"fɔɹ aʊɝz pæs mɪddeɪ," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"Four hours past midday," Galad said.

"jɔɹ sɝɾən?"

"You're certain?"

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"wɝnt wi tə stɑp ət mɪddeɪ tə dɪskʌs əɹ nɛkst stɛp?" ðət miɾɪŋ wɑz tə hæv teɪkən pleɪs wʌns ðeɪ ɡɑt θɹu ðə swɑmp.

"Weren't we to stop at midday to discuss our next step?" That meeting was to have taken place once they got through the swamp.

"fɔɹ naʊ, wɪv fju tʃɔɪsəz," ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ wɪl lid ðə mɛn nɔɹθwɝd tə ændɝ."

"For now, we have few choices," Galad said. "I will lead the men northward to Andor."

"ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əv mɛt . . . hɑstɪləɾi ðɛɹ."

"The Children have met . . . hostility there."

"aɪ hæv səm sɪkluɾɪd læn ʌp ɪn ðə nɔɹθwɛst. əl nɑt bi tɝn əweɪ ðɛɹ, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə hu kəntʃɹoʊlz ðə θɹoʊn."

"I have some secluded land up in the northwest. I will not be turned away there, regardless of who controls the throne."

laɪt sɛn ðəɾ ɪleɪn hɛl ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. laɪt sɛn ðət ʃi hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðə tæŋɡəlz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ hi fɪɹd ðə wɝst. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni hu wəd juz əɹ əz ə pɔn, ælθɹ nɑt ðə list ə ðɛm. ʃi wɑz hɛdstʃɹɔŋ, ən ðət kəd meɪk əɹ izi tə mənɪpjəleɪt.

Light send that Elayne held the Lion Throne. Light send that she had escaped the tangles of the Aes Sedai, though he feared the worst. There were many who would use her as a pawn, al'Thor not the least of them. She was headstrong, and that could make her easy to manipulate.

"wil nid səplaɪz," tʃɹɑm sɛd. "fɔɹɪdʒ ɪz dɪfəkəlt, ən mɔɹ ən mɔɹ vɪlədʒəz ɑɹ ɛmpti."

"We'll need supplies," Trom said. "Forage is difficult, and more and more villages are empty."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. ə lədʒɪɾəmət kənsɝn.

Galad nodded. A legitimate concern.

"ɪts ə ɡʊd plæn, ðoʊ," tʃɹɑm sɛd, ðən loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "aɪl ədmɪt, dəmədʒɹd, aɪ wɝid ðət jud ɹɛfjus liɾɝʃɪp."

"It's a good plan, though," Trom said, then lowered his voice. "I'll admit, Damodred, I worried that you'd refuse leadership."

"aɪ kəd nɑt. tə əbændən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən naʊ, æftɝ kɪlɪŋ ðɛɹ liɾɝ, wəd bi ɹɔŋ."

"I could not. To abandon the Children now, after killing their leader, would be wrong."

tʃɹɑm smaɪld. "ɪts əz sɪmpəl əz ðət tə ju, ɪzən ɪt?"

Trom smiled. "It's as simple as that to you, isn't it?"

"ɪt ʃəd bi əz sɪmpəl əz ðət tə ɛniwʌn." ɡɑləd hæd tə ɹaɪz tə ðə steɪʃən i hæd bɪn ɡɪvən. hi hæd noʊ ʌðɝ ɑpʃən. "ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmz ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɪl faɪt. ivən ɪf wɪv tə meɪk əlaɪənsəz wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf, wɪl faɪt."

"It should be as simple as that to anyone." Galad had to rise to the station he had been given. He had no other option. "The Last Battle comes and the Children of the Light will fight. Even if we have to make alliances with the Dragon Reborn himself, we will fight."

fəɹ səm taɪm, ɡɑləd hædn bɪn sɝɾən əbaʊɾ ælθɹ. sɝɾənli ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wəɾ əv tə faɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl. bʌt wɑz ðət mæn ælθɹ, əɹ wɑz i ə pʌpəɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ən nɑt ðə tʃɹu dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ðət skaɪ wɑz tu dɑɹk, ðə læn tu bɹoʊkən. ælθɹ mʌs bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

For some time, Galad hadn't been certain about al'Thor. Certainly the Dragon Reborn would have to fight at the Last Battle. But was that man al'Thor, or was he a puppet of the Tower, and not the true Dragon Reborn? That sky was too dark, the land too broken. Al'Thor must be the Dragon Reborn.

ðət dɪdn min, ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɾ i wɑzn ɔlsoʊ ə pʌpəɾ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

That didn't mean, of course, that he wasn't also a puppet of the Aes Sedai.

sun ðeɪ pæs bɪɑn ðə skɛləɾəl ɡɹeɪ tʃɹiz, ɹitʃɪŋ wʌnz ðət wɝ mɔɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi. ðiz stɪl hæd jɛloʊd livz, tu mɛni dɛd bɹæntʃəz. bʌt ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ðə fʌz.

Soon they passed beyond the skeletal gray trees, reaching ones that were more ordinary. These still had yellowed leaves, too many dead branches. But that was better than the fuzz.

əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, ɡɑləd noʊɾəd tʃaɪl bɑɹlɪt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. ðə skaʊt wɑz ə lin mæn, skɑɹɾ ɑn wʌn tʃik. ɡɑləd hɛld ʌp ə hæn əz ðə mæn əpɹoʊtʃt. "wʌt wɝd?"

About an hour later, Galad noted Child Barlett returning. The scout was a lean man, scarred on one cheek. Galad held up a hand as the man approached. "What word?"

bɑɹlɪt səluɾəd wɪð ɑɹm tə tʃɛst. "ðə swɑmp dʒɹaɪz aʊɾ ən ðə tʃɹiz θɪn ɪn əbaʊt wʌn maɪl, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. ðə fil bɪɑn ɪz oʊpən ən ɛmpti, ðə weɪ klɪɹ tə ðə nɔɹθ."

Barlett saluted with arm to chest. "The swamp dries out and the trees thin in about one mile, my Lord Captain Commander. The field beyond is open and empty, the way clear to the north."

laɪt bi θæŋkt! ɡɑləd θɔt. hi nɑɾəd tə bɑɹlɪt, ən ðə mæn hɝid bæk θɹu ðə tʃɹiz.

Light be thanked! Galad thought. He nodded to Barlett, and the man hurried back through the trees.

ɡɑləd ɡlæns bæk ət ðə laɪn ə mɛn. ðeɪ wɝ mʌɾid, swɛɾi, ən fətiɡd. bʌt stɪl, ðeɪ wɝ ə ɡɹæn saɪt, ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ɹipleɪst, ðɛɹ feɪsəz dɪtɝmənd. ðeɪ hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪm θɹu ðɪs pɪɾ ʌv ə swɑmp. ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd mɛn.

Galad glanced back at the line of men. They were muddied, sweaty, and fatigued. But still, they were a grand sight, their armor replaced, their faces determined. They had followed him through this pit of a swamp. They were good men.

"pæs ðə wɝd tə ði ʌðɝ lɔɹdz kæptən, tʃɹɑm," ɡɑləd sɛd. "hæv əm sɛnd wɝd tə ðɛɹ lidʒənz. wɪl bi aʊɾ ə ðɪs ɪn ʌndɝ ən aʊɝ."

"Pass the word to the other Lords Captain, Trom," Galad said. "Have them send word to their legions. We'll be out of this in under an hour."

ði oʊldɝ mæn smaɪld, lʊkɪŋ əz ɹɪlivd əz ɡɑləd fɛlt. ɡɑləd kəntɪnjuɾ ɔnwɝd, dʒɔ sɛɾ əɡɛns ðə peɪn ə hɪz lɛɡ. ðə kʌt wɑz wɛl baʊnd, ən ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl deɪnʒɝ ə fɝðɝ dæmədʒ. ɪt wɑz peɪnfəl, bʌt peɪn kəd bi dɛlt wɪð.

The older man smiled, looking as relieved as Galad felt. Galad continued onward, jaw set against the pain of his leg. The cut was well bound, and there was little danger of further damage. It was painful, but pain could be dealt with.

faɪnəli fɹi ʌv ðɪs bɑɡ! hi wəd nid tə plɑt ðɛɹ nɛks kɔɹs kɛɹfəli, steɪɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɛni taʊnz, meɪdʒɝ ɹoʊdz, əɹ ɪsteɪts hɛl baɪ ɪnfluɛntʃəl lɔɹdz. hi ɹæn θɹu ðə mæps ɪn ɪz hɛd - mæps mɛmɝaɪz bɪfɔɹ ɪz tɛnθ neɪmdeɪ.

Finally free of this bog! He would need to plot their next course carefully, staying away from any towns, major roads, or estates held by influential lords. He ran through the maps in his head - maps memorized before his tenth nameday.

hi wɑz ðʌs ɛnɡeɪdʒd wən ðə jɛloʊ kænəpi θɪnd, klaʊɾəd sʌnlaɪt pikɪŋ bɪtwin bɹæntʃəz. sun i kɑt saɪɾ ə bɑɹlɪt weɪɾɪŋ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə laɪn ə tʃɹiz. ðə fɔɹəst ɛndəɾ əbɹʌpli, ɔlmoʊst əz niɾ əz ə laɪn ɑn ə mæp.

He was thus engaged when the yellow canopy thinned, clouded sunlight peeking between branches. Soon he caught sight of Barlett waiting at the edge of the line of trees. The forest ended abruptly, almost as neat as a line on a map.

ɡɑləd saɪɾ ɪn ɹɪlif, ɹɛlɪʃɪŋ ðə θɔɾ ə biɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən əɡɛn. hi stɛp fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz. oʊnli ðən dɪɾ ən ɪnɔɹməs fɔɹs ə tʃɹups bɪɡɪn tə əpɪɹ, klaɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ ə ɹaɪz dɝɛkli tə hɪz ɹaɪt.

Galad sighed in relief, relishing the thought of being out in the open again. He stepped from the trees. Only then did an enormous force of troops begin to appear, climbing over a rise directly to his right.

ɑɹmɝ klæŋd, hɔɹsəz wɪniɪŋ, əz θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz laɪn ʌp ətɑp ðə ɹaɪz. səm wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪɾ ən meɪl, wɪð kɑnɪkəl hɛlmz ʃaɪn tə pɝfɛkʃən. ðɛɹ pɹɪstin tɑbɝdz ən kloʊks ʃoʊn, sʌnbɝsts ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ət ðə bɹɛsts, lænsɪz ɹeɪzd ɪn ɹæŋks. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ nʌmbɝ wɝ fʊt soʊlʒɝz, nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪɾ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd sɪmpəl bɹaʊn lɛðɝz. ɑmɑdɪʃənz, laɪkli pɹəvaɪɾəd baɪ ðə sintʃæn. mɛni hæd baʊz.

Armor clanged, horses whinnying, as thousands of soldiers lined up atop the rise. Some were Children in their plate and mail, with conical helms shined to perfection. Their pristine tabards and cloaks shone, sunbursts glittering at the breasts, lances raised in ranks. The larger number were foot soldiers, not wearing the white of the Children, but instead simple brown leathers. Amadicians, likely provided by the Seanchan. Many had bows.

ɡɑləd stʌmbəl bæk, hænd ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd. bʌɾ i nu, ɪmiɾiətli, ðəɾ i hæd bɪn tʃɹæpt. nɑɾ ə fju ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɔɹ kloʊðɪŋ ədɔɹnd wɪð ðə kɹʊk ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt -  ðə kwɛstʃənɝz. ɪf ɔɹɾənɛɹi tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ ə fleɪm tə bɝn əweɪ ivəl, ðə kwɛstʃənɝz wɝ ə ɹeɪdʒɪŋ bɑnfaɪɝ.

Galad stumbled back, hand going to his sword. But he knew, immediately, that he had been trapped. Not a few of the Children wore clothing adorned with the crook of the Hand of the Light -  the Questioners. If ordinary Children were a flame to burn away evil, the Questioners were a raging bonfire.

ɡɑləd dɪɾ ə kwɪk kaʊnt. θɹi tə fɔɹ θaʊzən tʃɪlʒɹən ən ət list ənʌðɝ sɪks tə eɪt θaʊzən fʊt, hæf ə ðoʊz wɪð baʊz. tɛn θaʊzən fɹɛʃ tʃɹups. hɪz hɑɹt sæŋk.

Galad did a quick count. Three to four thousand Children and at least another six to eight thousand foot, half of those with bows. Ten thousand fresh troops. His heart sank.

tʃɹɑm, bɔɹnhəld ən baɪɑɝ heɪsən aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəs bɪhaɪnd ɡɑləɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ə ɡɹup ʌv ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən. tʃɹɑm kɝst sɔfli.

Trom, Bornhald and Byar hastened out of the forest behind Galad along with a group of other Children. Trom cursed softly.

"soʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə ðə skaʊt, bɑɹlɪt, "ju ɑɹ ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ?"

"So," Galad said, turning to the scout, Barlett, "you are a traitor?"

"ju ɑɹ ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝ, tʃaɪl dəmədʒɹd," ðə skaʊt ɹɪplaɪd, feɪs hɑɹd.

"You are the traitor, Child Damodred," the scout replied, face hard.

"jɛs," ɡɑləd sɛd, "aɪ səpoʊz ɪt kəd bi pɝsiv ðət weɪ." ðɪs mɑɹtʃ θɹu ðə swɑmp hæd bɪn sədʒɛstəd baɪ hɪz skaʊts. ɡɑləd kəd si naʊ; ɪt hæd bɪn ə dɪleɪɪŋ tæktɪk, ə weɪ fəɹ əsunɑwə tə ɡɛɾ əhɛɾ ʌv ɡɑləd. ðə mɑɹtʃ hæɾ ɔlsoʊ lɛft ɡɑlədz mɛn taɪɝd waɪl əsunɑwəz fɔɹs wɑz fɹɛʃ ən ɹɛɾi fəɹ bæɾəl.

"Yes," Galad said, "I suppose it could be perceived that way." This march through the swamp had been suggested by his scouts. Galad could see now; it had been a delaying tactic, a way for Asunawa to get ahead of Galad. The march had also left Galad's men tired while Asunawa's force was fresh and ready for battle.

ə sɔɹd skɹeɪpt ɪn ɪts ʃiθ.

A sword scraped in its sheath.

ɡɑləɾ ɪmiɾiətli ɹeɪzd ə hænd wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ. "pis, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ." baɪɑɝ wʊɾə bɪn ðə wʌn tə ɹitʃ fəɹ ɪz wɛpən, pɹɑbli tə stʃɹaɪk daʊn bɑɹlɪt.

Galad immediately raised a hand without turning. "Peace, Child Byar." Byar would have been the one to reach for his weapon, probably to strike down Barlett.

pɝhæps sʌmθɪŋ ə ðɪs kəd bi sælvɪdʒd. ɡɑləd meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən swɪfli. "tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ ən tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld, jə ɑɹ wɪð mi. tʃɹɑm, jə ən ði ʌðɝ lɔɹdz kæptən bɹɪŋ əɹ mɛn aʊɾ ɪn ɹæŋks ɑntu ðə fild."

Perhaps something of this could be salvaged. Galad made his decision swiftly. "Child Byar and Child Bornhald, you are with me. Trom, you and the other Lords Captain bring our men out in ranks onto the field."

ə lɑɹdʒ klʌstɝ ə mɛn nɪɹ ðə fɹʌn ʌv əsunɑwəz fɔɹs wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd.

A large cluster of men near the front of Asunawa's force was riding forward, down the hillside.

mɛni wɔɹ ðə kɹʊk ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz. ðeɪ cʊɾə spɹʌŋ ðɛɹ æmbʊʃ ən kɪld ɡɑlədz ɡɹup kwɪkli. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ sɛn daʊn ə ɡɹup tə pɑɹli. ðət wɑz ə ɡʊd saɪn.

Many wore the crook of the Questioners. They could have sprung their ambush and killed Galad's group quickly. Instead, they sent down a group to parley. That was a good sign.

ɡɑləd maʊntəd, səpɹɛsɪŋ ə wɪns fəɹ ɪz wundəd lɛɡ. baɪɑɝ ən bɔɹnhəl maʊntəɾ əz wɛl, ən ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɑntu ðə fild, hʊfbits mʌfəl baɪ ðə θɪk, jɛloʊd ɡɹæs. əsunɑwə hɪmsɛlf wɑz əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹup əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. hi hæd θɪk, ɡɹeɪɪŋ aɪbɹaʊz ən wɑz soʊ θɪn əz tə əpɪɹ ə dɑl meɪɾ ə stɪks, wɪð fæbɹɪk stʃɹɛtʃt əkɹɔs əm tə ɪməteɪt skɪn.

Galad mounted, suppressing a wince for his wounded leg. Byar and Bornhald mounted as well, and they followed him onto the field, hoofbeats muffled by the thick, yellowed grass. Asunawa himself was among the group approaching. He had thick, graying eyebrows and was so thin as to appear a doll made of sticks, with fabric stretched across them to imitate skin.

əsunɑwə wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ. hi ɹɛɹli dɪd.

Asunawa was not smiling. He rarely did.

ɡɑləd pʊld ɪz hɔɹs ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ. əsunɑwə wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə smɔl ɡɑɹɾ ə hɪz kwɛstʃənɝz, bʌt wɑz ɔlsoʊ əkʌmpənid baɪ faɪv lɔɹdz kæptən, itʃ ə hum ɡɑləd hæd mɛt wɪð - əɹ sɝvd ʌndɝ - dʊɹɪŋ ɪz ʃɔɹt taɪm ɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən.

Galad pulled his horse up before the High Inquisitor. Asunawa was surrounded by a small guard of his Questioners, but was also accompanied by five Lords Captain, each of whom Galad had met with - or served under - during his short time in the Children.

əsunɑwə lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, sʌŋkən aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ. "jɔɹ ɹɛbəlz fɔɹm ɹæŋks. tɛl əm tə stæn daʊn əɹ maɪ ɑɹtʃɝz wɪl lus."

Asunawa leaned forward in his saddle, sunken eyes narrowing. "Your rebels form ranks. Tell them to stand down or my archers will loose."

"ʃʊɹli jə wəd nɑɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðə ɹulz ə fɔɹməl ɛnɡeɪdʒmənt?" ɡɑləd sɛd. "ju wəd dʒɹɔ æɹoʊz əpɑn mɛn əz ðeɪ fɔɹm ɹæŋks? wɛɹ ɪz jəɹ ɑnɝ?"

"Surely you would not ignore the rules of formal engagement?" Galad said. "You would draw arrows upon men as they form ranks? Where is your honor?"

"dɑɹkfɹɛnz dɪzɝv noʊ ɑnɝ," əsunɑwə snæpt. "nɔɹ də ðeɪ dɪzɝv pɪɾi."

"Darkfriends deserve no honor," Asunawa snapped. "Nor do they deserve pity."

"ju neɪm əs dɑɹkfɹɛnz ðɛn?" ɡɑləɾ æskt, tɝnɪŋ ɪz maʊn slaɪtli. "ɑ sɛvən θaʊzən tʃɪlʒɹən u wɝ ʌndɝ vɑldəz kəmænd? mɛn jəɹ soʊlʒɝz əv sɝvd wɪð, iɾən wɪð, noʊn ən fɔt bɪsaɪd? mɛn jə jɝsɛlf wɑtʃt oʊvɝ nɑt tu mʌnθs əɡoʊ?"

"You name us Darkfriends then?" Galad asked, turning his mount slightly. "AH seven thousand Children who were under Valda's command? Men your soldiers have served with, eaten with, known and fought beside? Men you yourself watched over not two months ago?"

əsunɑwə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. neɪmɪŋ sɛvən θaʊzən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əz dɑɹkfɹɛnz wəd bi ɹɪdɪkjələs -  ɪt wəd min ðət tu aʊɾ ə θɹi ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən hæd ɡɔn tə ðə ʃædoʊ.

Asunawa hesitated. Naming seven thousand of the Children as Darkfriends would be ridiculous -  it would mean that two out of three remaining Children had gone to the Shadow.

"noʊ," əsunɑwə sɛd. "pɝhæps ðeɪ ɑɹ sɪmpli . . . mɪsɡaɪɾɪd. ivən ə ɡʊd mæn kən stʃɹeɪ daʊn ʃæɾoʊd pæðz ɪf ɪz liɾɝz ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz."

"No," Asunawa said. "Perhaps they are simply . . . misguided. Even a good man can stray down shadowed paths if his leaders are Darkfriends."

"aɪ æm noʊ dɑɹkfɹɛnd." ɡɑləd mɛɾ əsunɑwəz aɪz.

"I am no Darkfriend." Galad met Asunawa's eyes.

"səbmɪt tə maɪ kwɛstʃənɪŋ ən pɹuv ɪt."

"Submit to my questioning and prove it."

"ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ sʌbmɪts hɪmsɛlf tə noʊ wʌn," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ ɔɹɾɝ jə tə stæn daʊn."

"The Lord Captain Commander submits himself to no one," Galad said. "Under the Light, I order you to stand down."

əsunɑwə læft. "tʃaɪld, wi hoʊld ə naɪf tə jəɹ θɹoʊt! ðɪs ɪz jəɹ tʃæns tə sɝɛndɝ!"

Asunawa laughed. "Child, we hold a knife to your throat! This is your chance to surrender!"

"ɡəlivɝ," ɡɑləd sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə lɔɹd kæptən əɾ əsunɑwəz lɛft. ɡəlivɝ wɑz ə læŋki, bɪɹɾəd mæn, əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ keɪm - bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlsoʊ fɛɹ. "tɛl mi, də ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt sɝɛndɝ?"

"Golever," Galad said, looking at the Lord Captain at Asunawa's left. Golever was a lanky, bearded man, as hard as they came - but he was also fair. "Tell me, do the Children of the Light surrender?"

ɡəlivɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wi də nɑt. ðə laɪt wɪl pɹuv əs vɪktɔɹiəs."

Golever shook his head. "We do not. The Light will prove us victorious."

"æn ɪf wi feɪs supɪɹiɝ ɑdz?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

"And if we face superior odds?" Galad asked.

"wi faɪɾ ɑn."

"We fight on."

"ɪf wəɹ taɪɝɾ ən sɔɹ?"

"If we are tired and sore?"

"ðə laɪt wɪl pɹətɛkt ʌs," ɡəlivɝ sɛd. "æn ɪf ɪts əɹ taɪm tə daɪ, ðən soʊ bi ɪt. lɛɾ əs teɪk əz mɛni ɛnəmiz wɪð əs əz wi meɪ."

"The Light will protect us," Golever said. "And if it is our time to die, then so be it. Let us take as many enemies with us as we may."

ɡɑləd tɝn bæk tə əsunɑwə. "ju si ðəɾ aɪm ɪn ə pɹɪdɪkəmənt. tə faɪɾ ɪz tə lɛt jə neɪm əs dɑɹkfɹɛnz, bʌt tə sɝɛndɝ ɪz tə dɪnaɪ əɹ oʊðz. baɪ maɪ ɑnɝ əz ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, aɪ kən æksɛp niðɝ ɑpʃən."

Galad turned back to Asunawa. "You see that I am in a predicament. To fight is to let you name us Darkfriends, but to surrender is to deny our oaths. By my honor as the Lord Captain Commander, I can accept neither option."

əsunɑwəz ɪkspɹɛʃən dɑɹkənd. "ju ɑɹ nɑt ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. hiz dɛd."

Asunawa's expression darkened. "You are not the Lord Captain Commander. He is dead."

"baɪ maɪ hænd," ɡɑləd sɛd, ənʃiðɪŋ ɪz wɛpən, hoʊldɪŋ ɪt fɔɹwɝd soʊ ðət ðə hɛɹənz ɡlimd ɪn ðə laɪt. "æn aɪ hoʊld ɪz sɔɹd. dʒju dɪnaɪ ðət jə jɝsɛlf wɑtʃt mi feɪs vɑldə ɪn fɛɹ kɑmbæt, əz pɹiskɹaɪbd baɪ lɔ?"

"By my hand," Galad said, unsheathing his weapon, holding it forward so that the herons gleamed in the light. "And I hold his sword. Do you deny that you yourself watched me face Valda in fair combat, as prescribed by law?"

"æz baɪ ðə lɔ, pɝhæps," əsunɑwə sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt kɔl ðət faɪt fɛɹ. jə dʒɹu ɑn ðə paʊɝz ə ʃædoʊ; aɪ sɔ jə stændɪŋ ɪn dɑɹknəs dɪspaɪt ðə deɪlaɪt, ən aɪ sɔ ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ spɹaʊɾ ɑn jəɹ fɔɹhɛd. vɑldə nɛvɝ hæɾ ə tʃæns."

"As by the law, perhaps," Asunawa said. "But I would not call that fight fair. You drew on the powers of Shadow; I saw you standing in darkness despite the daylight, and I saw the Dragon's Fang sprout on your forehead. Valda never had a chance."

"hɑɹnɪʃ," ɡɑləd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə ðə lɔɹd kæptən tə ðə ɹaɪɾ ʌv əsunɑwə. hi wɑz ə ʃɔɹt mæn, bɔld, mɪsɪŋ wʌn ɪɹ fɹəm faɪɾɪŋ dʒɹæɡ-ɑnsɔɹn. "tɛl mi. ɪz ðə ʃædoʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðə laɪt?"

"Harnesh," Galad said, turning to the Lord Captain to the right of Asunawa. He was a short man, bald, missing one ear from fighting Drag-onsworn. "Tell me. Is the Shadow stronger than the Light?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," ðə mæn sɛd, spɪɾɪŋ tə ðə saɪd.

"Of course not," the man said, spitting to the side.

"ɪf ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝz kɑz hæd bɪn ɑnɝəbəl, wəɾ i hæv fɔlən tə mi ɪn ə bæɾəl ʌndɝ ðə laɪt? ɪf aɪ wɝ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, kəɾ aɪ hæv sleɪn ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ hɪmsɛlf?"

"If the Lord Captain Commander's cause had been honorable, would he have fallen to me in a battle under the Light? If I were a Darkfriend, could I have slain the Lord Captain Commander himself?"

hɑɹnɪʃ dɪdn ænsɝ, bʌt ɡɑləd kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si ðə θɔts ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðə ʃædoʊ maɪt dɪspleɪ stʃɹɛŋkθ ət taɪmz, bʌt ðə laɪɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɪvild ən dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪt. ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl fəɹ ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ tə fɔl tə ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd - ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl fəɹ ɛni mæn tə fɔl. bʌɾ ɪn ə duəl bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən? ə duəl fəɹ ɑnɝ, ʌndɝ ðə laɪt?

Harnesh didn't answer, but Galad could almost see the thoughts in his head. The Shadow might display strength at times, but the Light always revealed and destroyed it. It was possible for the Lord Captain Commander to fall to a Darkfriend - it was possible for any man to fall. But in a duel before the other Children? A duel for honor, under the Light?

"səmtaɪmz ðə ʃædoʊ dɪspleɪz kʌnɪŋ ən stʃɹɛŋkθ," əsunɑwə kʌɾ ɪn bɪfɔɹ ɡɑləd kəd kəntɪnju tə kwɛstʃən. "æt taɪmz, ɡʊd mɛn daɪ."

"Sometimes the Shadow displays cunning and strength," Asunawa cut in before Galad could continue to question. "At times, good men die."

"ju ɔl noʊ wʌt vɑldə dɪd," ɡɑləd sɛd. "maɪ mʌðɝ ɪz dɛd. ɪz ðəɹ ən ɑɹɡjəmən əɡɛns maɪ ɹaɪt tə tʃælənʒ hɪm?"

"You all know what Valda did," Galad said. "My mother is dead. Is there an argument against my right to challenge him?"

"ju hæv noʊ ɹaɪts əz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd! əl pɑɹli noʊ mɔɹ wɪð ju, mɝɾɝɝ." əsunɑwə weɪvd ə hænd, ən sɛvɹəl ə hɪz kwɛstʃənɝz dʒɹu sɔɹdz. ɪmiɾiətli, ɡɑlədz kəmpænjənz dɪd ðə seɪm.

"You have no rights as a Darkfriend! I will parley no more with you, murderer." Asunawa waved a hand, and several of his Questioners drew swords. Immediately, Galad's companions did the same.

bɪhaɪnd, hi kəd hɪɹ ɪz wɪɹi fɔɹsɪz heɪstəli kloʊzɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹæŋks.

Behind, he could hear his weary forces hastily closing their ranks.

"wʌt wɪl hæpən tə ʌs, əsunɑwə, ɪf tʃaɪl faɪts tʃaɪld?" ɡɑləɾ æsk sɔfli. "aɪ wɪl nɑt sɝɛndɝ, ən aɪ wəd nɑɾ ətæk ju, bʌt pɝhæps wi kən ɹiunaɪt. nɑɾ əz ɛnəmiz, bʌɾ əz bɹʌðɝz sɛpɝeɪɾəd fəɹ ə taɪm."

"What will happen to us, Asunawa, if Child fights Child?" Galad asked softly. "I will not surrender, and I would not attack you, but perhaps we can reunite. Not as enemies, but as brothers separated for a time."

"aɪ wɪl nɛvɝ əsoʊsieɪt wɪð dɑɹkfɹɛnz," əsunɑwə sɛd, ðoʊ hi saʊndəd hɛzɪɾənt. hi wɑtʃt ɡɑlədz mɛn. əsunɑwə wəd wɪn ə bæɾəl, bʌɾ ɪf ɡɑlədz mɛn stʊd ðɛɹ ɡɹaʊnd, ɪt wəd bi ə kɑsli vɪktɝi. boʊθ saɪdz wəd luz θaʊzənz.

"I will never associate with Darkfriends," Asunawa said, though he sounded hesitant. He watched Galad's men. Asunawa would win a battle, but if Galad's men stood their ground, it would be a costly victory. Both sides would lose thousands.

"aɪ wɪl səbmɪt tə ju," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ɑn sɝɾən tɝmz."

"I will submit to you," Galad said. "On certain terms."

"noʊ!" bɔɹnhəl sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, bʌt ɡɑləd ɹeɪzd ə hænd, saɪlənsɪŋ hɪm.

"No!" Bornhald said from behind, but Galad raised a hand, silencing him.

"wʌt tɝmz wəd ðoʊz bi?" əsunɑwə æskt.

"What terms would those be?" Asunawa asked.

"ju swɛɹ - bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪɾ ən ðə lɔɹdz kæptən hɪɹ wɪð jə - ðət jəl nɑt hɑɹm, kwɛstʃən, əɹ ʌðɝwaɪz kəndɛm ðə mɛn u fɑloʊd mi. ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli duɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ θɔt wɑz ɹaɪt."

"You swear - before the Light and the Lords Captain here with you - that you will not harm, question, or otherwise condemn the men who followed me. They were only doing what they thought was right."

əsunɑwəz aɪz nɛɹoʊd, hɪz lɪps fɔɹmɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪt laɪn.

Asunawa's eyes narrowed, his lips forming a straight line.

"ðæɾ ɪnkludz maɪ kəmpænjənz hɪɹ," ɡɑləd sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə baɪɑɝ ən bɔɹnhəld. "ɛvɹi mæn, əsunɑwə. ðeɪ mʌs nɛvɝ noʊ kwɛstʃənɪŋ."

"That includes my companions here," Galad said, nodding to Byar and Bornhald. "Every man, Asunawa. They must never know questioning."

"ju kænɑt hɪndɝ ðə hæn ə ðə laɪɾ ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ! ðɪs wəd ɡɪv əm fɹi ɹeɪn tə sik ðə ʃædoʊ!"

"You cannot hinder the Hand of the Light in such a way! This would give them free rein to seek the Shadow!"

"æn ɪz ɪɾ oʊnli fɪɹ ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ ðət kips əs ɪn ðə laɪt, əsunɑwə?" ɡɑləɾ æskt. "ɑɹ nɑt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən væljən ən tʃɹu?"

"And is it only fear of Questioning that keeps us in the Light, Asunawa?" Galad asked. "Are not the Children valiant and true?"

əsunɑwə fɛl saɪlənt. ɡɑləd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, filɪŋ ðə weɪɾ ə liɾɝʃɪp. itʃ moʊmən i stɔld ɪnkɹis ðə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ pəzɪʃən fəɹ ɪz mɛn. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. "ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmz, əsunɑwə. wi hævən taɪm fəɹ skwɑbəlɪŋ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɔks ðə lænd."

Asunawa fell silent. Galad closed his eyes, feeling the weight of leadership. Each moment he stalled increased the bargaining position for his men. He opened his eyes. "The Last Battle comes, Asunawa. We haven't time for squabbling. The Dragon Reborn walks the land."

"hɛɹəsi!" əsunɑwə sɛd.

"Heresy!" Asunawa said.

"jɛs," ɡɑləd sɛd. "æn tʃɹuθ əz wɛl."

"Yes," Galad said. "And truth as well."

əsunɑwə ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ, bʌt sim tə bi kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ði ɔfɝ.

Asunawa ground his teeth, but seemed to be considering the offer.

"ɡɑləd," bɔɹnhəl sɛd sɔfli. "doʊn də ðɪs. wi kən faɪt. ðə laɪt wɪl pɹətɛkt ʌs!"

"Galad," Bornhald said softly. "Don't do this. We can fight. The Light will protect us!"

"ɪf wi faɪt, wɪl kɪl ɡʊd mɛn, tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld," ɡɑləd sɛd, wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ. "itʃ stʃɹoʊk ʌv əɹ sɔɹdz wɪl bi ə bloʊ fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ ði oʊnli tʃɹu faʊndeɪʃən ðət ðɪs wɝld əz lɛft. wəɹ niɾəd. ɪf maɪ laɪf ɪz wʌɾ ɪz dɪmændəd tə bɹɪŋ junəɾi, ðən soʊ bi ɪt. jə wəd də ðə seɪm, aɪ bɪliv." hi mɛɾ əsunɑwəz aɪz.

"If we fight, we will kill good men, Child Bornhald," Galad said, without turning. "Each stroke of our swords will be a blow for the Dark One. The Children are the only true foundation that this world has left. We are needed. If my life is what is demanded to bring unity, then so be it. You would do the same, I believe." He met Asunawa's eyes.

"teɪk hɪm," əsunɑwə snæpt, lʊkɪŋ dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. "æn tɛl ðə lidʒənz tə stæn daʊn. ɪnfɔɹm əm ðəɾ aɪ hæv teɪkən ðə fɔls lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ɪndə kʌstəɾi, ən wɪl kwɛstʃən ɪm tə dətɝmən ði ɪkstɛn ə hɪz kɹaɪmz." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ pæs ðə wɝd ðət ðoʊz u fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɑɹ nɑt tə bi pʌnɪʃt əɹ kwɛstʃənd." əsunɑwə spʌn ɪz hɔɹs ən ɹoʊɾ əweɪ.

"Take him," Asunawa snapped, looking dissatisfied. "And tell the legions to stand down. Inform them that I have taken the false Lord Captain Commander into custody, and will Question him to determine the extent of his crimes." He hesitated. "But also pass the word that those who followed him are not to be punished or Questioned." Asunawa spun his horse and rode away.

ɡɑləd tɝn ɪz sɔɹɾ ən hændəɾ ɪɾ aʊt tə bɔɹnhəld. "ɹɪtɝn tə əɹ mɛn; tɛl əm wʌt hæpən hɪɹ, ən də nɑt lɛɾ əm faɪɾ əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɛskju mi. ðəɾ ɪz ən ɔɹɾɝ."

Galad turned his sword and handed it out to Bornhald. "Return to our men; tell them what happened here, and do not let them fight or try to rescue me. That is an order."

bɔɹnhəl mɛɾ ɪz aɪz, ðən sloʊli tʊk ðə sɔɹd. ət læst, hi səluɾəd. "jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ."

Bornhald met his eyes, then slowly took the sword. At last, he saluted. "Yes, my Lord Captain Commander."

əz sun əz ðeɪ tɝn tə ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, ɹʌf hænz ɡɹæbd ɡɑləɾ ən pʊld ɪm fɹəm staʊts sæɾəl. hi hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, hɪz bæd ʃoʊldɝ θɹoʊɪŋ ə spaɪk ʌv æɡəni əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst.

As soon as they turned to ride away, rough hands grabbed Galad and pulled him from Stout's saddle. He hit the ground with a grunt, his bad shoulder throwing a spike of agony across his chest.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə klaɪm tə hɪz fit, bʌt sɛvɹəl kwɛstʃənɝz dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən nɑkt ɪm daʊn əɡɛn.

He tried to climb to his feet, but several Questioners dismounted and knocked him down again.

wʌn fɔɹst ɡɑləd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ə buɾ ɑn ɪz bæk, ən ɡɑləd hɝd ðə mətælɪk ɹæsp ʌv ə naɪf biɪŋ ənʃiðd. ðeɪ kʌɾ ɪz ɑɹmɝ ən kloʊðɪŋ fɹi.

One forced Galad to the ground, a boot on his back, and Galad heard the metallic rasp of a knife being unsheathed. They cut his armor and clothing free.

"ju wɪl nɑt wɛɹ ðə junəfɔɹm ʌv ə tʃaɪld ə ðə laɪt, dɑɹkfɹɛnd," ə kwɛstʃənɝ sɛɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹ.

"You will not wear the uniform of a Child of the Light, Darkfriend," a Questioner said in his ear.

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd," ɡɑləd sɛd, feɪs pɹɛs tə ðə ɡɹæsi ɝθ. "aɪ wɪl nɛvɝ spik ðət laɪ. aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt."

"I am not a Darkfriend," Galad said, face pressed to the grassy earth. "I will never speak that lie. I walk in the Light."

ðəɾ ɝn ɪm ə kɪk tə ðə saɪd, ðən ənʌðɝ, ən ənʌðɝ. hi kɝld ʌp, ɡɹʌntɪŋ. bʌt ðə bloʊz kəntɪnjud tə fɔl.

That earned him a kick to the side, then another, and another. He curled up, grunting. But the blows continued to fall.

faɪnəli, ðə dɑɹknəs tʊk hɪm.

Finally, the darkness took him.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd wʌns bɪn pdən feɪn wɔk daʊn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə hɪl. ðə bɹaʊn widz ɡɹu ɪn bɹoʊkən pætʃəz, laɪk ðə skɹʌb ɑn ðə tʃɪn ʌv ə bɛɡɝ.

The creature that had once been Padan Fain walked down the side of a hill. The brown weeds grew in broken patches, like the scrub on the chin of a beggar.

ðə skaɪ wɑz blæk. ə tɛmpəst. hi laɪk ðæt, ðoʊ hi heɪɾəd ðə wʌn u kɑzd ɪt.

The sky was black. A tempest. He liked that, though he hated the one who caused it.

heɪtʃɹəd. ɪt wɑz ðə pɹuf ðəɾ i stɪl lɪvd, ðə wʌn ɪmoʊʃən lɛft. ði oʊnli ɪmoʊʃən. ɪt wɑz ɔl ðət ðəɹ kəd bi.

Hatred. It was the proof that he still lived, the one emotion left. The only emotion. It was all that there could be.

kənsumɪŋ. θɹɪlɪŋ. bjuɾəfəl. wɔɹmɪŋ. vaɪələnt. heɪtʃɹəd. wʌndɝfəl. ɪt wɑz ðə stɔɹm ðət ɡeɪv ɪm stʃɹɛŋkθ, ðə pɝpəs ðət dʒɹoʊv hɪm. ælθɹ wəd daɪ. baɪ hɪz hænd. ən pɝhæps æftɝ ðæt, ðə dɑɹk wʌn. wʌndɝfəl . . .

Consuming. Thrilling. Beautiful. Warming. Violent. Hatred. Wonderful. It was the storm that gave him strength, the purpose that drove him. Al'Thor would die. By his hand. And perhaps after that, the Dark One. Wonderful . . .

ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn pdən feɪn fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz bjuɾəfəl dæɡɝ, filɪŋ ðə ɹɪdʒəz ə ðə dɪzaɪnz ɪn ðə faɪn ɡoʊldən waɪɝ ðət ɹæpt ɪts hɪlt. ə lɑɹdʒ ɹubi kæp ði ɛn ʌv ɪts hɪlt, ən i kæɹid ðə wɛpən ənʃiðd ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt hæn soʊ ðət ðə bleɪɾ ɪkstɛndəd bɪtwin ɪz fɝs tu fɪŋɡɝz. ðə saɪdz ə ðoʊz fɪŋɡɝz hæd bɪn kʌɾ ə dʌzən taɪmz oʊvɝ.

The creature that had been Padan Fain fingered his beautiful dagg'er, feeling the ridges of the designs in the fine golden wire that wrapped its hilt. A large ruby capped the end of its hilt, and he carried the weapon unsheathed in his right hand so that the blade extended between his first two fingers. The sides of those fingers had been cut a dozen times over.

blʌd dʒɹɪp fɹəm ðə tɪp ə ðə dæɡɝ daʊn ɑntu ðə widz. kɹɪmzən spɑts tə tʃɪɹ hɪm. ɹɛd bɪloʊ, blæk əbʌv. pɝfəkt. dɪɾ ɪz heɪtʃɹəd kɑz ðət stɔɹm? ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. jɛs.

Blood dripped from the tip of the dagger down onto the weeds. Crimson spots to cheer him. Red below, black above. Perfect. Did his hatred cause that storm? It must be so. Yes.

ðə dʒɹɑps ə blʌd fɛl əlɔŋsaɪd spɑts ə dɑɹknəs ðəɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn dɛd livz ən stɛmz əz i muv fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ ɪndə ðə blaɪt.

The drops of blood fell alongside spots of darkness that appeared on dead leaves and stems as he moved farther north into the Blight.

hi wɑz mæd. ðət wɑz ɡʊd. wən jə æksɛptɪd mædnəs ɪndə jɝsɛlf -  ɛmbɹeɪst ɪɾ ən dʒɹæŋk ɪɾ ɪn əz ɪf ɪt wɝ sʌnlaɪɾ əɹ wɔɾɝ əɹ ði ɛɹ ɪtsɛlf - ɪt bɪkeɪm ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə ju. laɪk ə hæn əɹ ən aɪ. jə kəd si baɪ mædnəs. jə kəd hoʊl θɪŋz wɪð mædnəs. ɪt wɑz wʌndɝfəl. lɪbɝeɪɾɪŋ.

He was mad. That was good. When you accepted madness into yourself -  embraced it and drank it in as if it were sunlight or water or the air itself - it became another part of you. Like a hand or an eye. You could see by madness. You could hold things with madness. It was wonderful. Liberating.

hi wɑz faɪnəli fɹi.

He was finally free.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn mɔɹɾɪθ ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɪl ən dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk ət ðə lɑɹdʒ, pɝplɪʃ mæs ðət hid lɛft ətɑp ɪt. wɝmz wɝ vɛɹi mɛsi tə kɪl ðə ɹaɪt weɪ, bʌt səm θɪŋz niɾəd tə bi dʌn ðə ɹaɪt weɪ. ɪt wɑz ðə pɹɪnsəpəl ə ðə θɪŋ.

The creature that had been Mordeth reached the bottom of the hill and did not look back at the large, purplish mass that he'd left atop it. Worms were very messy to kill the right way, but some things needed to be done the right way. It was the principle of the thing.

mɪs hæd bɪɡʌn tə tʃɹeɪl hɪm, kɹipɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. wɑz ðət mɪst ɪz mædnəs, əɹ wɑz ɪɾ ɪz heɪtʃɹəd? ɪt wɑz soʊ fəmɪljɝ. ɪt twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ɪz æŋkəlz ən lɪkt əɾ ɪz hilz.

Mist had begun to trail him, creeping up from the ground. Was that mist his madness, or was it his hatred? It was so familiar. It twisted around his ankles and licked at his heels.

sʌmθɪŋ pikt ɝaʊn ə hɪlsaɪd nɪɹbaɪ, ðən dʌk bæk. wɝmz daɪd laʊdli. wɝmz dɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ laʊdli. ə pæk ʌv wɝmz kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ən ɪntaɪɝ lidʒən. wən jə hɝd ðɛm, jə wɛn ði ʌðɝ weɪ, kwɪkli. bʌt ðɛn, ɪt kəd bi ædvənteɪdʒəs tə sɛn skaʊts tə ɡoʊ dʒʌdʒ ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə pæk, lɛs jə kəntɪnju ɑn ən ɹʌn əkɹɔs ɪɾ əɡɛn ɛlswɛɹ.

Something peeked around a hillside nearby, then ducked back. Worms died loudly. Worms did everything loudly. A pack of Worms could destroy an entire legion. When you heard them, you went the other way, quickly. But then, it could be advantageous to send scouts to go judge the direction of the pack, lest you continue on and run across it again elsewhere.

soʊ ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn pdən feɪn wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd wən i ɹaʊndəd ðə hɪlsaɪɾ ən faʊn ə nɝvəs ɡɹup ə tʃɹɑləks ðɛɹ, ə mɹdʒɹɑl ɡaɪɾɪŋ ðɛm.

So the creature that had been Padan Fain was not surprised when he rounded the hillside and found a nervous group of Trollocs there, a Myrddraal guiding them.

hi smaɪld. maɪ fɹɛnz. ɪt hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ.

He smiled. My friends. It had been too long.

ɪt tʊk ə moʊmən fəɹ ðɛɹ bɹuɾɪʃ bɹeɪnz tə kʌm tə ði ɑbviəs -  bʌt fɔls - kənkluʒən: ɪf ə mæn wɑz wɑndɝɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ðən wɝmz kʊdn bi nɪɹ. ðoʊz wʊɾə sɝnɛld ɪz blʌɾ ən kʌm fəɹ hɪm. wɝmz pɹəfɝd hjumənz oʊvɝ tʃɹɑləks. ðət meɪd sɛns. ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn mɔɹɾɪθ hæd teɪstəd boʊθ, ən tʃɹɑlɑk flɛʃ hæd lɪɾəl tə ɹɛkəmɛn ɪt.

It took a moment for their brutish brains to come to the obvious -  but false - conclusion: If a man was wandering around, then Worms couldn't be near. Those would have srnelled his blood and come for him. Worms preferred humans over Trollocs. That made sense. The creature that had been Mordeth had tasted both, and Trolloc flesh had little to recommend it.

ðə tʃɹɑləks tɔɹ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ə mɪsmætʃt pæk, fɛðɝz, biks, klɔz, tiθ, tʌsks. ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn feɪn stʊd stɪl, mɪs lɪkɪŋ ɪz ənʃɑd fit. haʊ wʌndɝfəl! ət ðə vɛɹi bæk ə ðə ɡɹup, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɪts aɪləs ɡeɪz fɪkst ɑn hɪm. pɝhæps ɪt sɛns ðət sʌmθɪŋ wɑz tɛɹəbli, tɛɹəbli ɹɔŋ. ən ɹaɪt, ʌv kɔɹs. jə kʊdn bi wʌn wɪθaʊt ði ʌðɝ. ðət wʊdn meɪk sɛns.

The Trollocs tore forward in a mismatched pack, feathers, beaks, claws, teeth, tusks. The creature that had been Fain stood still, mist licking his unshod feet. How wonderful! At the very back of the group, the Myrddraal hesitated, its eyeless gaze fixed on him. Perhaps it sensed that something was terribly, terribly wrong. And right, of course. You couldn't be one without the other. That wouldn't make sense.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn mɔɹɾɪθ - hi wəd niɾ ə nu neɪm sun - smaɪl dipli.

The creature that had been Mordeth - he would need a new name soon - smiled deeply.

ðə mɹdʒɹɑl tɝn tə ɹʌn əweɪ.

The Myrddraal turned to run away.

ðə mɪst stʃɹʌk.

The mist struck.

ɪt ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹɑləks, muvɪŋ kwɪkli, laɪk ðə tɛntəkəlz ʌv ə ləvaɪəθən ɪn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən.

It rolled over the Trollocs, moving quickly, like the tentacles of a leviathan in the Aryth Ocean.

lɛŋθs ʌv ɪt snæp fɔɹwɝd θɹu tʃɹɑlɑk tʃɛsts. wʌn lɔŋ ɹoʊp wɪpt əbʌv ðɛɹ hɛdz, ðən ʃɑt fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ə blɝ, teɪkɪŋ ðə feɪɾ ɪn ðə nɛk.

Lengths of it snapped forward through Trolloc chests. One long rope whipped above their heads, then shot forward in a blur, taking the Fade in the neck.

ðə tʃɹɑləks skɹimd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ, spæzəmɪŋ. ðɛɹ hɛɹ fɛl aʊɾ ɪn pætʃəz, ən ðɛɹ skɪn bɪɡæn tə bɔɪl. blɪstɝz ən sɪsts. wən ðoʊz pɑpt, ðeɪ lɛf kɹeɪɾɝlaɪk pɑks ɪn ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn skɪn, laɪk bʌbəlz ɑn ðə sɝfəs ə mɛɾəl ðət kul tu kwɪkli.

The Trollocs screamed, dropping, spasming. Their hair fell out in patches, and their skin began to boil. Blisters and cysts. When those popped, they left craterlike pocks in the Shadowspawn skin, like bubbles on the surface of metal that cooled too quickly.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd bɪn pdən feɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ ɪn ɡli, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz tə ðə tumʌltʃuəs blæk skaɪ ən ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz feɪs, lɪps pɑɹɾəd, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ɪz fist. æftɝ ɪt pæst, hi saɪd, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz dæɡɝ taɪɾɝ -  kʌɾɪŋ ɪz flɛʃ.

The creature that had been Padan Fain opened his mouth in glee, closing his eyes to the tumultuous black sky and raising his face, lips parted, enjoying his feast. After it passed, he sighed, holding his dagger tighter -  cutting his flesh.

ɹɛd bɪloʊ, blæk əbʌv. ɹɛɾ ən blæk, ɹɛɾ ən blæk, soʊ mʌtʃ ɹɛɾ ən blæk. wʌndɝfəl.

Red below, black above. Red and black, red and black, so much red and black. Wonderful.

hi wɔkt ɑn θɹu ðə blaɪt.

He walked on through the Blight.

ðə kɝʌptɪd tʃɹɑləks klaɪm tə ðɛɹ fit bɪhaɪn hɪm, lɝtʃɪŋ ɪndə moʊʃən, spɪɾəl dʒɹɑpɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ lɪps. ðɛɹ aɪz hæd ɡɹoʊn slʌɡɪʃ ən dʌl, bʌt wən i dɪzaɪɝɾ ɪt, ðeɪ wəd ɹɪspɑnd wɪð ə fɹɛnzid bæɾəl lʌs ðət wəd sɝpæs wʌt ðeɪ hæd noʊn ɪn laɪf.

The corrupted Trollocs climbed to their feet behind him, lurching into motion, spittle dropping from their lips. Their eyes had grown sluggish and dull, but when he desired it, they would respond with a frenzied battle lust that would surpass what they had known in life.

hi lɛf ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. ɪt wəd nɑt ɹaɪz, əz ɹumɝz sɛd ðeɪ dɪd. hɪz tʌtʃ naʊ bɹɔɾ ɪnstən dɛθ tə wʌn ʌv ɪts kaɪnd. pɪɾi. hi hæɾ ə fju neɪlz i maɪɾ əv ʌðɝwaɪz pʊt tə ɡʊd jus.

He left the Myrddraal. It would not rise, as rumors said they did. His touch now brought instant death to one of its kind. Pity. He had a few nails he might have otherwise put to good use.

pɝhæps i ʃəd ɡɛt səm ɡlʌvz. bʌɾ ɪf i dɪd, hi kʊdn kʌɾ ɪz hænd. wʌɾ ə pɹɑbləm.

Perhaps he should get some gloves. But if he did, he couldn't cut his hand. What a problem.

noʊ mæɾɝ. ɔnwɝd. ðə taɪm hæd kʌm tə kɪl ælθɹ.

No matter. Onward. The time had come to kill al'Thor.

ɪt sæɾənd ɪm ðət ðə hʌn mʌst ɛnd. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə ɹizən fəɹ ə hʌnt. jə dɪdn hʌn sʌmθɪŋ wən jə nu ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ɪt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə bi. jə mɪɹli ʃoʊɾ ʌp tə miɾ ɪt.

It saddened him that the hunt must end. But there was no longer a reason for a hunt. You didn't hunt something when you knew exactly where it was going to be. You merely showed up to meet it.

laɪk ən oʊl fɹɛnd. ə dɪɹ, bɪlʌvd oʊl fɹɛn ðət jə wɝ gɑnə stæb θɹu ði aɪ, oʊpən ʌp ət ðə ɡʌɾ ən kənsum baɪ hænfəlz waɪl dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪz blʌd. ðət wɑz ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ tə tʃɹit fɹɛnz.

Like an old friend. A dear, beloved old friend that you were going to stab through the eye, open up at the gut and consume by handfuls while drinking his blood. That was the proper way to treat friends.

ɪt wɑz ən ɑnɝ.

It was an honor.

mɑlənɝɪn ɹɑi ʃʌfəl θɹu səplaɪ ɹɪpɔɹts. ðət blæstəd ʃʌɾɝ ɑn ðə wɪndoʊ bɪhaɪn ɪz dɛsk snæpt ən blu oʊpən əɡɛn, lɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dæmp hiɾ ə ðə blaɪt.

Malenarin Rai shuffled through supply reports. That blasted shutter on the window behind his desk snapped and blew open again, letting in the damp heat of the Blight.

dɪspaɪt tɛn jɪɹz sɝvɪŋ əz kəmændɝ ə hiθ taʊɝ, hi hædnt ɡɹoʊn əkʌstəm tə ðə hiɾ ɪn ðə haɪlənz. dæmp. mʌɡi, ði ɛɹ ɔfən fʊl ə ɹɑɾɪŋ sɛns.

Despite ten years serving as commander of Heeth Tower, he hadn't grown accustomed to the heat in the highlands. Damp. Muggy, the air often full of rotting scents.

ðə wɪslɪŋ wɪn ɹæɾəld ðə wʊɾən ʃʌɾɝ. hi ɹoʊz, wɔkɪŋ oʊvɝ tə pʊl ɪt ʃʌt, ðən twɪstəɾ ə bɪɾ ə twaɪn ɝaʊn ɪts hændəl tə kip ɪt kloʊzd.

The whistling wind rattled the wooden shutter. He rose, walking over to pull it shut, then twisted a bit of twine around its handle to keep it closed.

hi wɔk bæk tə hɪz dɛsk, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɑstɝ ə nuli ɝaɪv soʊlʒɝz. itʃ neɪm hæɾ ə spɛʃəlti bɪsaɪɾ ɪt - ʌp hɪɹ, ɛvɹi soʊlʒɝ hæd tə fɪl tu əɹ mɔɹ duɾiz. skɪl ət baɪndɪŋ wunz.

He walked back to his desk, looking over the roster of newly arrived soldiers. Each name had a specialty beside it - up here, every soldier had to fill two or more duties. Skill at binding wounds.

swɪft fit fəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ mɛsədʒəz. ə kin aɪ wɪð ə baʊ. ði əbɪləɾi tə meɪk ðə seɪm oʊl mʌʃ teɪs laɪk nu mʌʃ. mɑlənɝɪn ɔlweɪz æsk spəsɪfɪkli fəɹ mɛn ɪn ðə læst ɡɹup. ɛni kʊk u kəd meɪk soʊlʒɝz iɡɝ tə kʌm tə mɛs wɑz wɝθ ɪz weɪɾ ɪn ɡoʊld.

Swift feet for running messages. A keen eye with a bow. The ability to make the same old mush taste like new mush. Malenarin always asked specifically for men in the last group. Any cook who could make soldiers eager to come to mess was worth his weight in gold.

mɑlənɝɪn sɛɾ əsaɪɾ ɪz kɝən ɹipɔɹt, weɪɪŋ ɪt daʊn wɪð ðə lɛd-fɪl tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn i kɛp fəɹ ðə pɝpəs. ðə nɛkst ʃiɾ ɪn ɪz stæk wɑz ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ə mæn neɪm bɑɹiɡə, ə mɝtʃən u wɑz bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz kæɹəvæn tə ðə taʊɝ tə tʃɹeɪd. mɑlənɝɪn smaɪld; hi wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ fɝst, bʌɾ i wɔɹ ðə θɹi sɪlvɝ tʃeɪnz əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛs ðət mɑɹkt ɪm əz ə mæstɝ mɝtʃənt. waɪl ɪz taʊɝ ɹəsiv mɛni ʌv ɪts səplaɪz dɝɛkli fɹəm ðə kwin, noʊ kændɔɹi kəmændɝ wɑz dɪnaɪd ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə bɑɹɾɝ wɪð mɝtʃəns.

Malenarin set aside his current report, weighing it down with the lead-filled Trolloc horn he kept for the purpose. The next sheet in his stack was a letter from a man named Barriga, a merchant who was bringing his caravan to the tower to trade. Malenarin smiled; he was a soldier first, but he wore the three silver chains across his chest that marked him as a master merchant. While his tower received many of its supplies directly from the Queen, no Kandori commander was denied the opportunity to barter with merchants.

ɪf i wɑz lʌki, hid bi eɪbəl tə ɡɛt ðɪs aʊtləndɝ mɝtʃən dʒɹʌŋk ət ðə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ teɪbəl.

If he was lucky, he'd be able to get this outlander merchant drunk at the bargaining table.

mɑlənɝɪn hæd fɔɹs mɔɹ ðən wʌn mɝtʃən ɪndə ə jɪɹ ə mɪlətɛɹi sɝvəs əz pɛnəns fəɹ ɛntɝɪŋ bɑɹɡənz i kəd nɑt kip. ə jɪɹ ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə kwinz fɔɹsɪz ɔfən dɪd plʌmp fɔɹən mɝtʃəns ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɡʊd.

Malenarin had forced more than one merchant into a year of military service as penance for entering bargains he could not keep. A year of training with the Queen's forces often did plump foreign merchants a great deal of good.

hi sɛt ðət ʃit bɪniθ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz i sɔ ðə læst aɪɾəm fəɹ ɪz ətɛnʃən ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stæk. ɪt wɑz ə ɹimaɪndɝ fɹəm ɪz stuɝd. kimlɪn, hɪz ɛldəst sʌn, wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɪz fɔɹtinθ neɪmdeɪ. əz ɪf mɑlənɝɪn kəd fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ðæt! hi niɾəd noʊ ɹimaɪndɝ.

He set that sheet beneath the Trolloc horn, then hesitated as he saw the last item for his attention at the bottom of the stack. It was a reminder from his steward. Keemlin, his eldest son, was approaching his fourteenth nameday. As if Malenarin could forget about that! He needed no reminder.

hi smaɪld, sɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn ɑn ðə noʊt, ɪn keɪs ðət ʃʌɾɝ bɹoʊk oʊpən əɡɛn. hid sleɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk u hæd bɔɹn ðət hɔɹn hɪmsɛlf. ðən i wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz ɔfəs ən oʊpən ɪz bæɾɝd oʊk tʃɹʌŋk. əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝ ɪfɛks ɪnsaɪd wɑz ə klɔθ-ɹæp sɔɹd, ðə bɹaʊn skæbɝd kɛpt wɛl ɔɪld ən meɪnteɪnd, bʌt feɪɾəd wɪð taɪm. hɪz fɑðɝz sɔɹd.

He smiled, setting the Trolloc horn on the note, in case that shutter broke open again. He'd slain the Trolloc who had borne that horn himself. Then he walked over to the side of his office and opened his battered oak trunk. Among the other effects inside was a cloth-wrapped sword, the brown scabbard kept well oiled and maintained, but faded with time. His father's sword.

ɪn θɹi deɪz, hi wəd ɡɪv ɪt tə kimlɪn. ə bɔɪ bɪkeɪm ə mæn ɑn ɪz fɔɹtinθ neɪmdeɪ, ðə deɪ hi wɑz ɡɪvən ɪz fɝst sɔɹɾ ən bɪkeɪm ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. kimlɪn hæd wɝk hɑɹd tə lɝn ɪz fɔɹmz ʌndɝ ðə hɑɹʃəs tʃɹeɪnɝz mɑlənɝɪn kəd pɹəvaɪd. sun ɪz sʌn wəd bɪkʌm ə mæn. haʊ kwɪkli ðə jɪɹz pæst.

In three days, he would give it to Keemlin. A boy became a man on his fourteenth nameday, the day he was given his first sword and became responsible for himself. Keemlin had worked hard to learn his forms under the harshest trainers Malenarin could provide. Soon his son would become a man. How quickly the years passed.

teɪkɪŋ ə pɹaʊd bɹɛθ, mɑlənɝɪn kloʊz ðə tʃɹʌŋk, ðən ɹoʊz ən lɛft ɪz ɔfəs fəɹ ɪz deɪli ɹaʊnz. ðə taʊɝ haʊz tu hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti soʊlʒɝz, ə bæstʃən ə dɪfɛns ðət wɑtʃt ðə blaɪt.

Taking a proud breath, Malenarin closed the trunk, then rose and left his office for his daily rounds. The tower housed two hundred and fifty soldiers, a bastion of defense that watched the Blight.

tə hæv ə duɾi wɑz tə hæv pɹaɪd - dʒʌst əz tə bɛɹ ə bɝɾən wɑz tə ɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ. wɑtʃɪŋ ðə blaɪt wɑz ɪz duɾi ən ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən ɪt wɑz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðiz deɪz, wɪð ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ stɔɹm tə ðə nɔɹθ, ən wɪð ðə kwin ən mʌtʃ ə ðə kændɔɹi ɑɹmi hævɪŋ mɑɹtʃt tə sik ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi pʊl ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɔfəs kloʊzd, ðən θɹu ðə hɪɾən lætʃ ðət bɑɹɾ ɪɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə sɛvɹəl sətʃ dɔɹz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ; ən ɛnəmi stɔɹmɪŋ ðə taʊɝ wʊdnt noʊ wɪtʃ wʌn oʊpən ɑntu ðə stɛɹwɛl ʌpwɝd. ɪn ðɪs weɪ, ə smɔl ɔfəs kəd fʌŋkʃən əz pɑɹɾ ə ðə taʊɝ dɪfɛns.

To have a duty was to have pride - just as to bear a burden was to gain strength. Watching the Blight was his duty and his strength, and it was particularly important these days, with the strange storm to the north, and with the Queen and much of the Kandori army having marched to seek the Dragon Reborn. He pulled the door to his office closed, then threw the hidden latch that barred it on the other side. It was one of several such doors in the hallway; an enemy storming the tower wouldn't know which one opened onto the stairwell upward. In this way, a small office could function as part of the tower defense.

hi wɔk tə ðə stɛɹwɛl. ðiz tɑp lɛvəlz wɝ nɑɾ æksɛsəbəl fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn lɛvəl - ði ɪntaɪɝ bɑɾəm fɔɹɾi fiɾ ə ðə taʊɝ wɑz ə tʃɹæp. ən ɛnəmi hu ɛntɝɾ ət ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ ən klaɪmd ʌp θɹi flaɪts ʌv ɡɛɹɪsən kɔɹɾɝz wəd dɪskʌvɝ noʊ weɪ ʌp tə ðə fɔɹθ flɔɹ. ði oʊnli weɪ tə ɡoʊ tə ðə fɔɹθ lɛvəl wɑz tə klaɪm ə nɛɹoʊ, kəlæpsəbəl ɹæmp ɑn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ðət lɛd fɹəm ðə sɛkən lɛvəl ʌp tə ðə fɔɹθ. ɹʌnɪŋ ɑn ɪt lɛft ətækɝz fʊli ɪkspoʊz tə æɹoʊz fɹəm əbʌv. ðɛn, wʌns səm ə ðɛm wɝ ʌp bʌɾ ʌðɝz nɑt, ðə kændɔɹi wəd kəlæps ðə ɹæmp, dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ði ɛnəmi fɔɹs ən livɪŋ ðoʊz əbʌv tə bi kɪld əz ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn ði ɪntɪɹiɝ stɛɹwəlz.

He walked to the stairwell. These top levels were not accessible from the ground level - the entire bottom forty feet of the tower was a trap. An enemy who entered at the ground floor and climbed up three flights of garrison quarters would discover no way up to the fourth floor. The only way to go to the fourth level was to climb a narrow, collapsible ramp on the outside of the tower that led from the second level up to the fourth. Running on it left attackers fully exposed to arrows from above. Then, once some of them were up but others not, the Kandori would collapse the ramp, dividing the enemy force and leaving those above to be killed as they tried to find the interior stairwells.

mɑlənɝɪn klaɪmd əɾ ə bɹɪsk peɪs. pɪɹiɑɾɪk slɪts tə ðə saɪdz ə ðə stɛps lʊk daʊn ɑn ðə stɛɹz bɪniθ, ən wəɾ əlaʊ ɑɹtʃɝz tə faɪɝ ɑn ɪnveɪɾɝz. wən i wɑz əbaʊt hæfweɪ tə ðə tɑp, hi hɝd heɪsti fʊtfɔlz kʌmɪŋ daʊn. ə sɛkən leɪɾɝ, dʒɑɹɡən - sɑɹdʒən ə ðə wɑtʃ - ɹaʊndəd ðə bɛnd.

Malenarin climbed at a brisk pace. Periodic slits to the sides of the steps looked down on the stairs beneath, and would allow archers to fire on invaders. When he was about halfway to the top, he heard hasty footfalls coming down. A second later, Jargen - sergeant of the watch - rounded the bend.

laɪk moʊs kændɔɹi, dʒɑɹɡən wɔɹ ə fɔɹk bɪɹd; hɪz blæk hɛɹ wɑz dʌstɪd wɪð ɡɹeɪ.

Like most Kandori, Jargen wore a forked beard; his black hair was dusted with gray.

dʒɑɹɡən hæd dʒɔɪn ðə blaɪtwɑtʃ ðə deɪ æftɝ ɪz fɔɹtinθ neɪm-deɪ. hi wɔɹ ə kɔɹd lupt ɝaʊn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ə hɪz bɹaʊn junəfɔɹm; ɪt bɔɹ ə nɑt fəɹ itʃ tʃɹɑlɑk hid kɪld. ðəɹ hæd tə bi əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ fɪfti nɑts ɪn ðə θɪŋ baɪ naʊ.

Jargen had joined the Blightwatch the day after his fourteenth name-day. He wore a cord looped around the shoulder of his brown uniform; it bore a knot for each Trolloc he'd killed. There had to be approaching fifty knots in the thing by now.

dʒɑɹɡən səluɾəd wɪð ɑɹm tə bɹɛst, ðən loʊɝɾ ɪz hæn tə ɹɛst ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, ə saɪn ə ɹɪspɛk fəɹ ɪz kəmændɝ. ɪn mɛni kʌntʃɹiz, hoʊldɪŋ ðə wɛpən laɪk ðət wəd bi ən ɪnsəlt, bʌt sʌðɝnɝz wɝ noʊn tə bi pivɪʃ ən ɪl-tɛmpɝd. kʊdn ðeɪ si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ən ɑnɝ tə hoʊl jəɹ sɔɹɾ ən ɪmplaɪ jə faʊn jəɹ kəmændɝ ə wɝði θɹɛt?

Jargen saluted with arm to breast, then lowered his hand to rest on his sword, a sign of respect for his commander. In many countries, holding the weapon like that would be an insult, but Southerners were known to be peevish and ill-tempered. Couldn't they see that it was an honor to hold your sword and imply you found your commander a worthy threat?

"maɪ lɔɹd," dʒɑɹɡən sɛd, vɔɪs ɡɹʌf. "ə flæʃ fɹəm ɹinə taʊɝ."

"My Lord," Jargen said, voice gruff. "A flash from Rena Tower."

"wʌt?" mɑlənɝɪn æskt. ðə tu fɛl ɪndə stɛp, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ʌp ðə stɛɹwɛl.

"What?" Malenarin asked. The two fell into step, trotting up the stairwell.

"ɪt wɑz dɪstɪŋkt, sɝ," dʒɑɹɡən sɛd. "sɔ ɪt maɪsɛlf, aɪ dɪd. oʊnli ə flæʃ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ."

"It was distinct, sir," Jargen said. "Saw it myself, I did. Only a flash, but it was there."

"dɪd ðeɪ sɛn ə kɝɛkʃən?"

"Did they send a correction?"

"ðeɪ meɪ hæv baɪ naʊ. aɪ ɹæn tə fɛtʃ jə fɝst."

"They may have by now. I ran to fetch you first."

ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɔɹ nuz, dʒɑɹɡən wʊɾə ʃɛɹɾ ɪt, soʊ mɑlənɝɪn dɪd nɑt weɪs bɹɛθ pɹɛsɪŋ hɪm. ʃɔɹtli, ðeɪ stɛpt ʌp ɑntu ðə tɑp ə ðə taʊɝ, wɪtʃ hɛld ən ɪnɔɹməs mɛkənɪzəm ə mɪɹɝz ən læmps. wɪð ði æpɝæɾəs, ðə taʊɝ kəd sɛn mɛsədʒəz tə ði ist əɹ wɛst - wɛɹ ʌðɝ taʊɝz laɪn ðə blaɪt - əɹ saʊθwɝd, əlɔŋ ə laɪn ə taʊɝz ðət ɹæn tə ði ɛɛzdeɪʃɝ pæləs ɪn tʃeɪkɪn.

If there had been more news, Jargen would have shared it, so Malenarin did not waste breath pressing him. Shortly, they stepped up onto the top of the tower, which held an enormous mechanism of mirrors and lamps. With the apparatus, the tower could send messages to the east or west - where other towers lined the Blight - or southward, along a line of towers that ran to the Aesdaishar Palace in Chachin.

ðə væst, ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ kændɔɹi haɪlənz spɹɛɾ aʊt fɹəm ɪz taʊɝ. səm ə ðə sʌðɝn hɪlz wɝ stɪl laɪtli leɪst wɪð mɔɹnɪŋ fɑɡ. ðət læn tə ðə saʊθ, fɹi ʌv ðɪs ənnætʃɹəl hit, wəd sun ɡɹoʊ ɡɹin, ən kændɔɹi hɝdzmɪn wəd klaɪm tə ðə haɪ pæstʃɝz tə ɡɹeɪz ðɛɹ ʃip.

The vast, undulating Kandori highlands spread out from his tower. Some of the southern hills were still lightly laced with morning fog. That land to the south, free of this unnatural heat, would soon grow green, and Kandori herdsmen would climb to the high pastures to graze their sheep.

nɔɹθwɝd leɪ ðə blaɪt. mɑlənɝɪn hæd ɹɛɾ ə deɪz wən ðə blaɪt hæd bɛɹli bɪn vɪzəbəl fɹəm ðɪs taʊɝ. naʊ ɪt ɹæn nɪɹli tə ðə beɪs ə ðə stoʊnwɝk. ɹinə taʊɝ wɑz nɔɹθwɛst əz wɛl. ɪts kəmændɝ - lɔɹd naɪɑk ə haʊs oʊkətoʊmoʊ - wɑz ə dɪstən kʌzən ən ə ɡʊd fɹɛnd. hi wəd nɑɾ əv sɛn ə flæʃ wɪθaʊt ɹizən, ən wəd sɛn ə ɹitʃɹækʃən ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn ən æksəɾənt.

Northward lay the Blight. Malenarin had read of days when the Blight had barely been visible from this tower. Now it ran nearly to the base of the stonework. Rena Tower was northwest as well. Its commander - Lord Niach of House Okatomo - was a distant cousin and a good friend. He would not have sent a flash without reason, and would send a retraction if it had been an accident.

"ɛni fɝðɝ wɝd?" mɑlənɝɪn æskt.

"Any further word?" Malenarin asked.

ðə soʊlʒɝz ɑn wɑtʃ ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz. dʒɑɹɡən tæpt ɪz fʊt, ən mɑlənɝɪn foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz tə weɪt fəɹ ə kɝɛkʃən.

The soldiers on watch shook their heads. Jargen tapped his foot, and Malenarin folded his arms to wait for a correction.

nʌθɪŋ keɪm. ɹinə taʊɝ stʊd wɪðɪn ðə blaɪt ðiz deɪz, əz ɪt wɑz fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ ðən hiθ taʊɝ. ɪts pəzɪʃən wɪðɪn ðə blaɪt wɑz nɔɹməli nɑɾ ən ɪʃu. ivən ðə moʊs fɪɹsəm kɹitʃɝz ə ðə blaɪt nu nɑt tə ətæk ə kændɔɹi taʊɝ.

Nothing came. Rena Tower stood within the Blight these days, as it was farther north than Heeth Tower. Its position within the Blight was normally not an issue. Even the most fearsome creatures of the Blight knew not to attack a Kandori tower.

noʊ kɝɛkʃən keɪm. nɑɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ. "sɛn ə mɛsədʒ tə ɹinə," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd. 'æsk ɪf ðɛɹ flæʃ wɑz ə mɪsteɪk. ðən æsk fɑɹm taʊɝ ɪf ðeɪv noʊɾəst ɛniθɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ."

No correction came. Not a glimmer. "Send a message to Rena," Malenarin said. 'Ask if their flash was a mistake. Then ask Farmay Tower if they have noticed anything strange."

dʒɑɹɡən sɛt ðə mɛn tə wɝk, bʌt ɡeɪv mɑlənɝɪn ə flæt ɡlæns, əz ɪf tə æsk, "ju θɪŋk aɪ hævən dʌn ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi?"

Jargen set the men to work, but gave Malenarin a flat glance, as if to ask, "You think I haven't done that already?"

ðət mɛn mɛsədʒəz hæd bɪn sɛnt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɝd bæk. wɪn blu əkɹɔs ðə taʊɝ tɑp, kɹikɪŋ ðə stil ə ðə mɪɹɝ æpɝæɾəs əz ɪz mɛn sɛn ənʌðɝ sɪɹiz ə flæʃɪz. ðət wɪnd wɑz hjuməd. fɑɹ tu hɑt. mɑlənɝɪn ɡlænst ʌpwɝd, təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðət seɪm blæk stɔɹm bɔɪld ən ɹoʊld. ɪt sim tə hæv sɛɾəld daʊn.

That meant messages had been sent, but there was no word back. Wind blew across the tower top, creaking the steel of the mirror apparatus as his men sent another series of flashes. That wind was humid. Far too hot. Malenarin glanced upward, toward where that same black storm boiled and rolled. It seemed to have settled down.

ðət stʃɹʌk ɪm əz vɛɹi dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ.

That struck him as very discomforting.

"flæʃ ə mɛsədʒ bækwɝd," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd, "təwɔɹd ði ɪnlæn taʊɝz. tɛl əm wʌt wi sɔ;

"Flash a message backward," Malenarin said, "toward the inland towers. Tell them what we saw;

tɛl əm tə bi ɹɛɾi ɪn keɪs ə tʃɹʌbəl."

tell them to be ready in case of trouble."

ðə mɛn sɛt tə wɝk.

The men set to work.

"sɑɹdʒənt," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd, "hu ɪz nɛkst ɑn ðə mɛsənʒɝ ɹɑstɝ?"

"Sergeant," Malenarin said, "who is next on the messenger roster?"

ðə taʊɝ fɔɹs ɪnkluɾəd ə smɔl ɡɹup ə bɔɪz u wɝ ɛksələn ɹaɪɾɝz. laɪtweɪt, ðeɪ kəd ɡoʊ ɑn fæs hɔɹsəz ʃəɾ ə kəmændɝ dɪsaɪd tə baɪpæs ðə mɪɹɝz. mɪɹɝ laɪt wɑz fæst, bʌɾ ɪt kəd bi sin baɪ wʌnz ɛnəmiz. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf ðə laɪn ə taʊɝz wɑz bɹoʊkən - əɹ ɪf ði æpɝæɾəs wɑz dæmədʒd - ðeɪ wəd niɾ ə minz tə ɡɛt wɝd tə ðə kæpəɾəl.

The tower force included a small group of boys who were excellent riders. Lightweight, they could go on fast horses should a commander decide to bypass the mirrors. Mirror light was fast, but it could be seen by one's enemies. Besides, if the line of towers was broken - or if the apparatus was damaged - they would need a means to get word to the capital.

"nɛkst ɑn ðə ɹɑstɝ . . ." dʒɑɹɡən sɛd, tʃɛkɪŋ ə lɪs neɪl tə ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ ɑntu ðə ɹuftɑp. "ɪt wəd bi kimlɪn, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Next on the roster . . ." Jargen said, checking a list nailed to the inside of the door onto the rooftop. "It would be Keemlin, my Lord."

kimlɪn. hɪz kimlɪn.

Keemlin. His Keemlin.

mɑlənɝɪn ɡlæns tə ðə nɔɹθwɛst, təwɔɹd ðə saɪlən taʊɝ ðət hæd flæʃt soʊ ɑmənəsli. "bɹɪŋ mi wɝɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə hɪn ə ɹɪspɑns fɹəm ði ʌðɝ taʊɝz," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd tə ðə soʊlʒɝz. "dʒɑɹɡən, kʌm wɪð mi."

Malenarin glanced to the northwest, toward the silent tower that had flashed so ominously. "Bring me word if there is a hint of response from the other towers," Malenarin said to the soldiers. "Jargen, come with me."

ðə tu ʌv əm hɝid daʊn ðə stɛɹz. "wi nid tə sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ saʊθwɝd," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "noʊ. noʊ, wi nid tə sɛn sɛvɹəl mɛsənʒɝz. dʌbəl ʌp. dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ðə taʊɝz fɔl." hi bɪɡæn muvɪŋ əɡɛn.

The two of them hurried down the stairs. "We need to send a messenger southward," Malenarin said, then hesitated. "No. No, we need to send several messengers. Double up. Just in case the towers fall." He began moving again.

ðə tu ʌv əm lɛf ðə stɛɹwɛl ən ɛntɝd mɑlənɝɪnz ɔfəs. hi ɡɹæbd ɪz bɛs kwɪl ɔf ðə ɹæk ɑn ɪz wɔl. ðət blæstəd ʃʌɾɝ wɑz bloʊɪŋ ən ɹætlɪŋ əɡɛn; ðə peɪpɝz ɑn ɪz dɛsk ɹʌsəld əz i pʊld aʊɾ ə fɹɛʃ ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ.

The two of them left the stairwell and entered Malenarin's office. He grabbed his best quill off the rack on his wall. That blasted shutter was blowing and rattling again; the papers on his desk rustled as he pulled out a fresh sheet of paper.

ɹinə ən fɑɹm nɑt ɹɪspɑndɪŋ tə flæʃ mɛsədʒəz. pɑsəbli oʊvɝɹʌn əɹ səvɪɹli hæmpɝd. bi ædvaɪzd. hiθ wɪl stænd.

Rena and Farmay not responding to flash messages. Possibly overrun or severely hampered. Be advised. Heeth will stand.

hi foʊldəd ðə peɪpɝ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp tə dʒɑɹɡən. ðə mæn tʊk ɪt wɪð ə lɛðɝi hænd, ɹɛɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ, ðən ɡɹʌntɪd. "tu kɑpiz, ðɛn?"

He folded the paper, holding it up to Jargen. The man took it with a leathery hand, read it over, then grunted. "Two copies, then?"

"θɹi," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd. "moʊbəlaɪz ði ɑɹtʃɝz ən sɛn əm tə ðə ɹuf. tɛl əm deɪnʒɝ meɪ kʌm fɹəm əbʌv."

"Three," Malenarin said. "Mobilize the archers and send them to the roof. Tell them danger may come from above."

ɪf i wɑzn mɪɹli dʒʌmpɪŋ ət ʃædoʊz - ɪf ðə taʊɝz tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hiθ hæd fɔlən soʊ kwɪkli - ðən soʊ kəd ðoʊz tə ðə saʊθ. ən ɪf hid bɪn ðə wʌn meɪkɪŋ ən əsɔlt, hiɾ əv dʌn ɛniθɪŋ i kəd tə snik ɝaʊn ən teɪk aʊt wʌn ə ðə sʌðɝn taʊɝz fɝst. ðət wɑz ðə bɛst weɪ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ mɛsədʒəz ɡɑt bæk tə ðə kæpəɾəl.

If he wasn't merely jumping at shadows - if the towers to either side of Heeth had fallen so quickly - then so could those to the south. And if he'd been the one making an assault, he'd have done anything he could to sneak around and take out one of the southern towers first. That was the best way to make sure no messages got back to the capital.

dʒɑɹɡən səluɾəd, fɪs tə tʃɛst, ðən wɪθdʒɹu. ðə mɛsədʒ wəd bi sɛn ɪmiɾiətli: θɹi taɪmz ɑn lɛɡz ə hɔɹsflɛʃ, wʌns ɑn lɛɡz ə laɪt. mɑlənɝɪn lɛt hɪmsɛlf fil ə hɪn ə ɹɪlif ðəɾ ɪz sʌn wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə seɪfti. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dɪsɑnɝ ɪn ðæt; ðə mɛsədʒəz niɾəd tə bi dɪlɪvɝd, ən kimlɪn wɑz nɛkst ɑn ðə ɹɑstɝ.

Jargen saluted, fist to chest, then withdrew. The message would be sent immediately: three times on legs of horseflesh, once on legs of light. Malenarin let himself feel a hint of relief that his son was one of those riding to safety. There was no dishonor in that; the messages needed to be delivered, and Keemlin was next on the roster.

mɑlənɝɪn ɡlænst aʊɾ ɪz wɪndoʊ. ɪt feɪs nɔɹθ, təwɔɹd ðə blaɪt. ɛvɹi kəmændɝz ɔfəs dɪd ðæt. ðə bʌbəlɪŋ stɔɹm, wɪð ɪts sɪlvɝi klaʊdz. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ lʊk laɪk stʃɹeɪt dʒiəmɛtʃɹɪk ʃeɪps. hi hæd lɪsənd wɛl tə pæsɪŋ mɝtʃəns. tʃɹʌbəl taɪmz wɝ kʌmɪŋ. ðə kwin wəd nɑɾ əv ɡɔn saʊθ tə sik ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ kʌnɪŋ əɹ ɪnfluɛntʃəl i maɪt bi. ʃi bɪlivd.

Malenarin glanced out his window. It faced north, toward the Blight. Every commander's office did that. The bubbling storm, with its silvery clouds. Sometimes they looked like straight geometric shapes. He had listened well to passing merchants. Troubled times were coming. The Queen would not have gone south to seek a false Dragon, no matter how cunning or influential he might be. She believed.

ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən. ən lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðət stɔɹm, mɑlənɝɪn θɔɾ i kəd si tə ðə vɛɹi ɛdʒ ə taɪm ɪtsɛlf. ən ɛdʒ ðət wɑz nɑt fɑɹ dɪstənt. ɪn fækt, ɪt sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹkɝ. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə dɑɹknəs bɪniθ ɪt, ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd nɔɹθwɝd.

It was time for Tarmon Gai'don. And looking out into that storm, Malenarin thought he could see to the very edge of time itself. An edge that was not far distant. In fact, it seemed to be growing darker. And there was a darkness beneath it, on the ground northward.

ðət dɑɹknəs wɑz ədvænsɪŋ.

That darkness was advancing.

mɑlənɝɪn dæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, ɹeɪsɪŋ ʌp ðə stɛps tə ðə ɹuf, wɛɹ ðə wɪn swɛpt əɡɛns mɛn pʊʃɪŋ ən muvɪŋ mɪɹɝz.

Malenarin dashed out of the room, racing up the steps to the roof, where the wind swept against men pushing and moving mirrors.

"wɑz ðə mɛsədʒ sɛn tə ðə saʊθ?" hi dɪmændəd.

"Was the message sent to the south?" he demanded.

"jɛs, sɝ," lutɛnən lændəlɪn sɛd. hid bɪn ɹaʊz tə teɪk kəmæn ə ðə taʊɝz tɑp. "noʊ ɹɪplaɪ jɛt."

"Yes, sir," Lieutenant Landalin said. He'd been roused to take command of the tower's top. "No reply yet."

mɑlənɝɪn ɡlæns daʊn, ən pɪkt aʊt θɹi ɹaɪɾɝz bɹeɪkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ ət fʊl spid.

Malenarin glanced down, and picked out three riders breaking away from the tower at full speed.
