ðə mɛsənʒɝz wɝ ɔf. ðeɪ wəd stɑp ət bɑɹklən ɪf ɪt wɑzn biɪŋ ətækt. ðə kæptən ðəɹ wəd sɛn əm ɑn saʊθwɝd, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. ən ɪf bɑɹklən dɪdn stænd, ðə bɔɪz wəd kəntɪnju ɑn, ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə kæpəɾəl ɪf niɾəd.

The messengers were off. They would stop at Barklan if it wasn't being attacked. The captain there would send them on southward, just in case. And if Barklan didn't stand, the boys would continue on, all the way to the capital if needed.

mɑlənɝɪn tɝn bæk tə ðə stɔɹm. ðəɾ ədvænsɪŋ dɑɹknəs hæɾ ɪm ɑn ɛdʒ. ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ.

Malenarin turned back to the storm. That advancing darkness had him on edge. It was coming.

"ɹeɪz ðə hɔɹɾɪŋz," hi ɔɹɾɝd lændəlɪn. "bɹɪŋ ʌp ðə stɔɹ hɪtʃ-ɪŋz ən ɛmpti ðə sɛlɝz.

"Raise the hoardings," he ordered Landalin. "Bring up the store hitch-ings and empty the cellars.

hæv ðə loʊɾɝz ɡæðɝ ɔl ə ði æɹoʊz ən sɛɾ ʌp steɪʃənz fəɹ ɹisʌplaɪɪŋ ði ɑɹtʃɝz, ən pʊɾ ɑɹtʃɝz əɾ ɛvɹi tʃoʊk pɔɪnt, kɪl slɪɾ ən wɪndoʊ. stɑɹt ðə faɪɝpɑts ən əv mɛn ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɑp ði aʊɾɝ ɹæmps. pɹipɛɹ fəɹ ə sidʒ."

Have the loaders gather all of the arrows and set up stations for resupplying the archers, and put archers at every choke point, kill slit and window. Start the firepots and have men ready to drop the outer ramps. Prepare for a siege."

əz lændəlɪn bɑɹkt ɔɹɾɝz, mɛn ɹʌʃt əweɪ. mɑlənɝɪn hɝd buts skɹeɪp stoʊn bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən i ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. wɑz ðət dʒɑɹ-dʒɛnɝəl bæk əɡɛn?

As Landalin barked orders, men rushed away. Malenarin heard boots scrape stone behind him, and he glanced over his shoulder. Was that Jar-gen back again?

noʊ. ɪt wɑz ə juθ ə nɪɹli fɔɹtin sʌmɝz, tu jʌŋ fəɹ ə bɪɹd, hɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ dɪʃɛvəld, hɪz feɪs stʃɹimɪŋ wɪð swɛt kɑzd -  pɹəzuməbli - baɪ ə ɹʌn ʌp sɛvən lɛvəlz ə ðə taʊɝ.

No. It was a youth of nearly fourteen summers, too young for a beard, his dark hair disheveled, his face streaming with sweat caused -  presumably - by a run up seven levels of the tower.

kimlɪn. mɑlənɝɪn fɛlt ə stæb ə fɪɹ, ɪnstənli ɹipleɪst wɪð æŋɡɝ. "soʊlʒɝ! jə wɝ tə ɹaɪd wɪð ə mɛsədʒ!"

Keemlin. Malenarin felt a stab of fear, instantly replaced with anger. "Soldier! You were to ride with a message!"

kimlɪn bɪɾ ɪz lɪp. "wɛl, sɝ," hi sɛd. "tʃjɑn, fɔɹ pleɪsəz daʊn fɹəm mi. hiz faɪv, meɪbi tɛn paʊnz laɪɾɝ ðən aɪ. ɪt meɪks ə bɪɡ dɪfɝəns, sɝ. hi ɹaɪdz ə lɑt fæstɝ, ən aɪ fɪɡjɝd ðɪs wəd bi ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt mɛsədʒ. soʊ aɪ æsk fəɹ ɪm tə bi sɛn ɪn maɪ pleɪs."

Keemlin bit his lip. "Well, sir," he said. "Tian, four places down from me. He is five, maybe ten pounds lighter than I. It makes a big difference, sir. He rides a lot faster, and I figured this would be an important message. So I asked for him to be sent in my place."

mɑlənɝɪn fɹaʊnd. soʊlʒɝz muvd ɝaʊn ðɛm, ɹʌʃɪŋ daʊn ðə stɛɹz əɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ wɪð baʊz ət ðə ɹɪm ə ðə taʊɝ. ðə wɪn haʊld aʊtsaɪɾ ən θʌndɝ bɪɡæn tə saʊn sɔfli - jɛɾ ɪnsɪstənli.

Malenarin frowned. Soldiers moved around them, rushing down the stairs or gathering with bows at the rim of the tower. The wind howled outside and thunder began to sound softly - yet insistently.

kimlɪn mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. "tʃjɑnz mʌðɝ, leɪɾi jəbəθ, hæz lɔs fɔɹ sʌnz tə ðə blaɪt," hi sɛd, sɔfli ɪnʌf ðəɾ oʊnli mɑlənɝɪn kəd hɪɹ. "tʃjɑnz ði oʊnli wʌn ʃiz lɛft. ɪf wʌn ʌv əs əz ə ʃɑɾ ət ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt, sɝ, aɪ fɪɡjɝɾ ɪt ʃəd bi hɪm."

Keemlin met his eyes. "Tian's mother, Lady Yabeth, has lost four sons to the Blight," he said, softly enough that only Malenarin could hear. "Tian's the only one she has left. If one of us has a shot at getting out, sir, I figured it should be him."

mɑlənɝɪn hɛld ɪz sʌnz aɪz. ðə bɔɪ ʌndɝstʊd wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ. laɪt hɛlp hɪm, bʌɾ i ʌndɝstʊd. ən hid sɛn ənʌðɝ əweɪ ɪn ɪz pleɪs.

Malenarin held his son's eyes. The boy understood what was coming. Light help him, but he understood. And he'd sent another away in his place.

"kɹeɪl," mɑlənɝɪn bɑɹkt, ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz pæsɪŋ baɪ.

"Kralle," Malenarin barked, glancing toward one of the soldiers passing by.

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd kəmændɝ?"

"Yes, my Lord Commander?"

"ɹʌn daʊn tə maɪ ɔfəs," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə sɔɹɾ ɪn maɪ oʊeɪkən tʃɹʌŋk. fɛtʃ ɪt fəɹ mi."

"Run down to my office," Malenarin said. "There is a sword in my oaken trunk. Fetch it for me."

ðə mæn səluɾəd, oʊbeɪɪŋ.

The man saluted, obeying.

"fɑðɝ?" kimlɪn sɛd. "maɪ neɪmdeɪ ɪzən fəɹ θɹi deɪz."

"Father?" Keemlin said. "My nameday isn't for three days."

mɑlənɝɪn weɪɾəd wɪð ɑɹmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hɪz moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsk ət ðə moʊmənt wɑz tə bi sin ɪn kəmænd, tə ɹiəʃʊɹ ɪz tʃɹups. kɹeɪl ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ðə sɔɹd; ɪts wɔɹn skæbɝd bɔɹ ði ɪmədʒ ə ði oʊk sɛɾ əfleɪm. ðə sɪmbəl ə haʊs ɹɑi.

Malenarin waited with arms behind his back. His most important task at the moment was to be seen in command, to reassure his troops. Kralle returned with the sword; its worn scabbard bore the image of the oak set aflame. The symbol of House Rai.

"fɑðɝ. . . ." kimlɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd. "aɪ - "

"Father. . . ." Keemlin repeated. "I - "

"ðɪs wɛpən ɪz ɔfɝd tə ə bɔɪ wən i bɪkʌmz ə mæn," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd. "ɪt simz ɪts tu leɪɾ ɪn kʌmɪŋ, sʌn. fəɹ aɪ si ə mæn stændɪŋ bɪfɔɹ mi." hi hɛl ðə wɛpən fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt hænd.

"This weapon is offered to a boy when he becomes a man," Malenarin said. "It seems it is too late in coming, son. For I see a man standing before me." He held the weapon forward in his right hand.

ɝaʊn ðə taʊɝ tɑp, soʊlʒɝz tɝn təwɔɹd hɪm: ði ɑɹtʃɝz wɪð baʊz ɹɛɾi, ðə soʊlʒɝz u ɑpɝeɪɾəd ðə mɪɹɝz, ðə duɾi wɑtʃmən. əz bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, itʃ ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm wʊɾə bɪn ɡɪvən ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹtinθ neɪm-deɪ. itʃ wʌn hæd fɛl ðə kætʃ ɪn ðə tʃɛst, ðə wʌndɝfəl filɪŋ ə kʌmɪŋ ʌv eɪdʒ. ɪt hæd hæpən tə itʃ ə ðɛm, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk ðɪs əkeɪʒən ɛni lɛs spɛʃəl.

Around the tower top, soldiers turned toward him: the archers with bows ready, the soldiers who operated the mirrors, the duty watchmen. As Borderlanders, each and every one of them would have been given his sword on his fourteenth name-day. Each one had felt the catch in the chest, the wonderful feeling of coming of age. It had happened to each of them, but that did not make this occasion any less special.

kimlɪn wɛn daʊn ɑn wʌn ni.

Keemlin went down on one knee.

"waɪ dʒju dʒɹɔ jəɹ sɔɹd?" mɑlənɝɪn æskt, vɔɪs laʊd soʊ ðəɾ ɛvɹi mæn ətɑp ðə taʊɝ wəd hɪɹ.

"Why do you draw your sword?" Malenarin asked, voice loud so that every man atop the tower would hear.

"ɪn dɪfɛns ə maɪ ɑnɝ, maɪ fæmli, əɹ maɪ hoʊmlænd," kimlɪn ɹɪplaɪd.

"In defense of my honor, my family, or my homeland," Keemlin replied.

"haʊ lɔŋ dʒju faɪt?"

"How long do you fight?"

"əntɪl maɪ læs bɹɛθ dʒɔɪnz ðə nɔɹðɝn wɪnz."

"Until my last breath joins the northern winds."

"wɛn dʒju stɑp wɑtʃɪŋ?"

"When do you stop watching?"

"nɛvɝ," kimlɪn wɪspɝd.

"Never," Keemlin whispered.

"spik ɪt laʊɾɝ!"

"Speak it louder!"

"nɛvɝ!"

"Never!"

"wʌns ðɪs sɔɹɾ ɪz dʒɹɔn, jə bɪkʌm ə wɔɹiɝ, ɔlweɪz wɪð ɪt nɪɹ jə ɪn pɹɛpɝeɪʃən tə faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ. wɪl jə dʒɹɔ ðɪs bleɪɾ ən dʒɔɪn ʌs, əz ə mæn?"

"Once this sword is drawn, you become a warrior, always with it near you in preparation to fight the Shadow. Will you draw this blade and join us, as a man?"

kimlɪn lʊkt ʌp, ðən tʊk ðə hɪlt ɪn ə fɝm ɡɹɪp ən pʊl ðə wɛpən fɹi.

Keemlin looked up, then took the hilt in a firm grip and pulled the weapon free.

"ɹaɪz əz ə mæn, maɪ sʌn!" mɑlənɝɪn dɪklɛɹd.

"Rise as a man, my son!" Malenarin declared.

kimlɪn stʊd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə wɛpən əlɔft, ðə bɹaɪt bleɪd ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə dɪfjus sʌnlaɪt. ðə mɛn ətɑp ðə taʊɝ tʃɪɹd.

Keemlin stood, holding the weapon aloft, the bright blade reflecting the diffuse sunlight. The men atop the tower cheered.

ɪt wɑz noʊ ʃeɪm tə faɪn tɪɹz ɪn wʌnz aɪz ət sətʃ ə moʊmənt. mɑlənɝɪn blɪŋkt əm fɹi, ðən nɛl daʊn, bʌklɪŋ ðə sɔɹd bɛlt əɾ ɪz sʌnz weɪst. ðə mɛn kəntɪnjud tə tʃɪɹ ən jɛl, ən i nu ɪt wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli fəɹ ɪz sʌn. ðeɪ jɛld ɪn dɪfaɪəns ə ðə ʃædoʊ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz ɹæŋ laʊɾɝ ðən ðə θʌndɝ.

It was no shame to find tears in one's eyes at such a moment. Malenarin blinked them free, then knelt down, buckling the sword belt at his son's waist. The men continued to cheer and yell, and he knew it was not only for his son. They yelled in defiance of the Shadow. For a moment, their voices rang louder than the thunder.

mɑlənɝɪn stʊd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪz sʌnz ʃoʊldɝ əz ðə bɔɪ slɪɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ.

Malenarin stood, laying a hand on his son's shoulder as the boy slid his sword into its sheath.

təɡɛðɝ ðeɪ tɝn tə feɪs ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ ʃædoʊ. ðɛɹ!" wʌn ə ði ɑɹtʃɝz sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ʌpwɝd.

Together they turned to face the oncoming Shadow. There!" one of the archers said, pointing upward.

"ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə klaʊdz!"

"There's something in the clouds!"

"dʒɹæɡkɝ!" ənʌðɝ wʌn sɛd.

"Draghkar!" another one said.

ði ənnætʃɹəl klaʊdz wɝ kloʊs naʊ, ən ðə ʃeɪd ðeɪ kæs kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ haɪd ði ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ hɔɹɾ ə tʃɹɑləks bɪniθ. sʌmθɪŋ flu aʊt fɹəm ðə skaɪ, bʌɾ ə dʌzən ə hɪz ɑɹtʃɝz lɛt lus. ðə kɹitʃɝ skɹimd ən fɛl, dɑɹk wɪŋz flæpɪŋ ɔkwɝdli.

The unnatural clouds were close now, and the shade they cast could no longer hide the undulating horde of Trollocs beneath. Something flew out from the sky, but a dozen of his archers let loose. The creature screamed and fell, dark wings flapping awkwardly.

dʒɑɹɡən pʊʃt ɪz weɪ θɹu tə mɑlənɝɪn. "maɪ lɔɹd," dʒɑɹɡən sɛd, ʃuɾɪŋ ə ɡlæns ət kimlɪn, "ðə bɔɪ ʃəd bi bɪloʊ."

Jargen pushed his way through to Malenarin. "My Lord," Jargen said, shooting a glance at Keemlin, "the boy should be below."

"nɑɾ ə bɔɪ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ," mɑlənɝɪn sɛd wɪð pɹaɪd. "ə mæn. wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ ɹipɔɹt?"

"Not a boy any longer," Malenarin said with pride. "A man. What is your report?"

"ɔl ɪz pɹipɛɹd." dʒɑɹɡən ɡlænst oʊvɝ ðə wɔl, aɪɪŋ ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ tʃɹɑləks əz ivənli əz ɪf i wɝ ɪnspɛktɪŋ ə steɪbəl ə hɔɹsəz. "ðeɪ wɪl nɑt faɪn ðɪs tʃɹi ən izi wʌn tə fɛl."

"All is prepared." Jargen glanced over the wall, eyeing the oncoming Trollocs as evenly as if he were inspecting a stable of horses. "They will not find this tree an easy one to fell."

mɑlənɝɪn nɑɾəd. kimlɪn ɛs ʃoʊldɝ wɑz tɛns. ðət si ʌv tʃɹɑləks simd ɛnləs. əɡɛns ðɪs foʊ, ðə taʊɝ wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli fɔl. ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd kip kʌmɪŋ, weɪv æftɝ weɪv.

Malenarin nodded. Keemlin s shoulder was tense. That sea of Trollocs seemed endless. Against this foe, the tower would eventually fall. The Trollocs would keep coming, wave after wave.

bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn ətɑp ðət taʊɝ nu hɪz duɾi. ðeɪd kɪl ʃædoʊ-spɑn əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kʊd, hoʊpɪŋ tə baɪ ɪnʌf taɪm fəɹ ðə mɛsədʒəz tə də səm ɡʊd.

But every man atop that tower knew his duty. They'd kill Shadow-spawn as long as they could, hoping to buy enough time for the messages to do some good.

mɑlənɝɪn wɑz ə mæn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, seɪm əz ɪz fɑðɝ, seɪm əz ɪz sʌn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðeɪ nu ðɛɹ tæsk. jə hɛld əntɪl jə wɝ ɹɪlivd.

Malenarin was a man of the Borderlands, same as his father, same as his son beside him. They knew their task. You held until you were relieved.

ðæts ɔl ðəɹ wɑz tə ɪt.

That's all there was to it.


tʃæptɝ wʌn


CHAPTER 1

æpəlz fɝst


Apples First

ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnz, ən eɪdʒəz kʌm ən pæs, livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət bɪkʌm lɛdʒənd. lɛdʒən feɪdz tə mɪθ, ən ivən mɪθ ɪz lɔŋ fɝɡɑɾən wən ði eɪdʒ ðət ɡeɪv ɪt bɝθ kʌmz əɡɛn. ɪn wʌn eɪdʒ, kɔl ðə θɝɾ eɪdʒ baɪ sʌm, ən eɪdʒ jɛt tə kʌm, ən eɪdʒ lɔŋ pæst, ə wɪn ɹoʊz əbʌv ðə mɪsti piks ʌv ɪmfɹəl. ðə wɪnd wɑz nɑt ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ niðɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋz nɔɹ ɛndɪŋz tə ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil ə taɪm. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

The Wheel of Time turns, and Ages come and pass, leaving memories that become legend. Legend fades to myth, and even myth is long forgotten when the Age that gave it birth comes again. In one Age, called the Third Age by some, an Age yet to come, an Age long past, a wind rose above the misty peaks of Imfaral. The wind was not the beginning. There are neither beginnings nor endings to the turning of the Wheel of Time. But it was a beginning.

kɹɪsp ən laɪt, ðə wɪn dænst əkɹɔs filz ə nu maʊntən ɡɹæs stɪf wɪð fɹɔst. ðət fɹɔs lɪŋɡɝd pæs fɝs laɪt, ʃɛltɝd baɪ ði ɑmnɪpɹɛzən klaʊdz ðət hʌŋ laɪk ə dɛθ mæsk haɪ əbʌv. ɪt hæd bɪn wiks sɪns ðoʊz klaʊdz hæd bʌdʒd, ən ðə wɑn, jɛloʊd ɡɹæs ʃoʊɾ ɪt.

Crisp and light, the wind danced across fields of new mountain grass stiff with frost. That frost lingered past first light, sheltered by the omnipresent clouds that hung like a death mask high above. It had been weeks since those clouds had budged, and the wan, yellowed grass showed it.

ðə wɪn tʃɝn mɔɹnɪŋ mɪst, muvɪŋ saʊθwɝd, tʃɪlɪŋ ə smɔl pɹaɪɾ ə tɔɹm. ðeɪ ɹɛklən ɑn ə flæt, laɪkən-steɪnd ɡɹænət ʃɛlf, weɪɾɪŋ tə bæsk ɪn mɔɹnɪŋ sʌnlaɪt ðət wəd nɑɾ ɝaɪv. ðə wɪn pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə ʃɛlf, ɹeɪsɪŋ daʊn ə hɪlsaɪɾ ə skɹæɡli mʊɹə tʃɹiz, wɪð ɹoʊpɪlaɪk bɑɹk ən ɡɹin tʌfs ə θɪk, niɾəllaɪk livz ətɑp ðɛm.

The wind churned morning mist, moving southward, chilling a small pride of torm. They reclined on a flat, lichen-stained granite shelf, waiting to bask in morning sunlight that would not arrive. The wind poured over the shelf, racing down a hillside of scraggly mura trees, with ropelike bark and green tufts of thick, needlelike leaves atop them.

ət ðə beɪs ə ðə fʊthɪlz, ðə wɪn tɝn istwɝd, pæsɪŋ ən oʊpən pleɪn kɛp fɹi ʌv tʃɹiz ən skɹʌb baɪ ðə soʊlʒɝz æks. ðə kɪlɪŋ fil sɝaʊndəd θɝtin fɔɹtʃɹəsəz, tɔl ən kʌɾ ɪntaɪɝli fɹəm ʌnpəlɪʃt blæk mɑɹbəl, ðɛɹ blɑks lɛft ɹʌf-hjun tə ɡɪv əm ə pɹaɪməl filɪŋ ɛf ənfɔɹm stʃɹɛŋkθ. ðiz wɝ taʊɝz mɛn fəɹ wɔɹ. baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən ðeɪ wɝ ənɑkjəpaɪd. haʊ lɔŋ ðət wəd læst - haʊ lɔŋ tʃɹədɪʃən ɪtsɛlf wəd bi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn ə kɑntənən ɪn keɪɑs - ɹɪmeɪn tə bi sin.

At the base of the foothills, the wind turned eastward, passing an open plain kept free of trees and scrub by the soldier's axe. The killing field surrounded thirteen fortresses, tall and cut entirely from unpolished black marble, their blocks left rough-hewn to give them a primal feeling f unformed strength. These were towers meant for war. By tradition they were unoccupied. How long that would last - how long tradition itself would be remembered in a continent in chaos - remained to be seen.

ðə wɪn kəntɪnjuɾ istwɝd, ən sun ɪt wɑz pleɪɪŋ wɪð ðə mæsts ə hæf-bɝnd ʃɪps ət ðə dɑks ə tækɪsɹəm. aʊɾ ɪndə ðə slipɪŋ beɪ, ɪt pæs ði ətækɝz: ɪnɔɹməs ɡɹieɪtʃɪps wɪð seɪlz peɪntəd blʌd ɹɛd. ðeɪ seɪl saʊθwɝd, ðɛɹ ɡɹɪzli wɝk dʌn.

The wind continued eastward, and soon it was playing with the masts of half-burned ships at the docks of Takisrom. Out into the Sleeping Bay, it passed the attackers: enormous greatships with sails painted blood red. They sailed southward, their grisly work done.

ðə wɪn blu ɑntu læn əɡɛn, pæst smoʊldɝɪŋ taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz, oʊpən pleɪnz fɪld wɪð tʃɹups ən dɑks fæt wɪð wɔɹʃɪps. smoʊk, wɔɹ kɔlz ən bænɝz flu əbʌv daɪɪŋ ɡɹæs ən bɪniθ ə dɑkmæstɝz ɡlumi skaɪ.

The wind blew onto land again, past smoldering towns and villages, open plains filled with troops and docks fat with warships. Smoke, war calls and banners flew above dying grass and beneath a dockmaster's gloomy sky.

mɛn dɪd nɑt wɪspɝ ðət ðɪs maɪt bi ði ɛn ə taɪmz. ðeɪ jɛld ɪt. ðə filz ə pis wɝ əfleɪm, ðə taʊɝ ə ɹeɪvənz wɑz bɹoʊkən əz pɹɑfəsaɪɾ ən ə mɝɾɝɝ oʊpənli ɹuld ɪn sindɑɹ. ðɪs wɑz ə taɪm tə lɪft wʌnz sɔɹɾ ən tʃuz ə saɪd, ðən spɪl blʌd tə ɡɪv ə faɪnəl kʌlɝ tə ðə daɪɪŋ lænd.

Men did not whisper that this might be the end of times. They yelled it. The Fields of Peace were aflame, the Tower of Ravens was broken as prophesied and a murderer openly ruled in Seandar. This was a time to lift one's sword and choose a side, then spill blood to give a final color to the dying land.

ðə wɪn haʊld istwɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə feɪmd ɛmɹəl klɪfs ən kɔɹst aʊɾ oʊvɝ ði oʊʃən.

The wind howled eastward over the famed Emerald Cliffs and coursed out over the ocean.

bɪhaɪnd, smoʊk sim tə ɹaɪz fɹəm ði ɪntaɪɝ kɑntənən ə sintʃæn.

Behind, smoke seemed to rise from the entire continent of Seanchan.

fəɹ aʊɝz, ðə wɪn blu - meɪkɪŋ wʌt wʊɾə bɪn kɔl tʃɹeɪdwaɪnz ɪn ənʌðɝ eɪdʒ -  twɪstɪŋ bɪtwin waɪtkæps ən dɑɹk, mɪstɪɹiəs weɪvz. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðə wɪn ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ənʌðɝ kɑntənənt, ðɪs wʌn kwaɪət, laɪk ə mæn hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ ðə hɛdzmənz æks fɛl.

For hours, the wind blew - making what would have been called tradewinds in another Age -  twisting between whitecaps and dark, mysterious waves. Eventually, the wind encountered another continent, this one quiet, like a man holding his breath before the headsman's axe fell.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðə wɪn ɹitʃt ði ɪnɔɹməs, bɹoʊkən-pik maʊntən noʊn əz dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, ɪt hæd lɔs mʌtʃ ʌv ɪts stʃɹɛŋkθ. ɪt pæst ɝaʊn ðə beɪs ə ðə maʊntən, ðən θɹu ə lɑɹdʒ ɔɹtʃɝɾ ʌv æpəl tʃɹiz, lɪt baɪ ɝli-æftɝnun sʌnlaɪt. ðə wʌns-ɡɹin livz hæd feɪɾəd tə jɛloʊ.

By the time the wind reached the enormous, broken-peaked mountain known as Dragonmount, it had lost much of its strength. It passed around the base of the mountain, then through a large orchard of apple trees, lit by early-afternoon sunlight. The once-green leaves had faded to yellow.

ðə wɪn pæs baɪ ə loʊ wʊɾən fɛns, taɪɾ əɾ ɪts dʒɔɪns wɪð tæn lɪnən twaɪn. tu fɪɡjɝz stʊd ðɛɹ: ə juθ ən ə sɑmbɝ mæn ɪn ɪz leɪɾɝ jɪɹz. ði oʊldɝ mæn wɔɹ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɔɹn bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə lus waɪt ʃɝt wɪð wʊɾən bʌɾənz. hɪz feɪs wɑz soʊ fɝoʊd wɪð ɹɪŋkəlz ðəɾ ɪt sim kɪn tə ðə bɑɹk ə ðə tʃɹiz.

The wind passed by a low wooden fence, tied at its joints with tan linen twine. Two figures stood there: a youth and a somber man in his later years. The older man wore a pair of worn brown trousers and a loose white shirt with wooden buttons. His face was so furrowed with wrinkles that it seemed kin to the bark of the trees.

ɑlmɛn bʌn dɪdnt noʊ ə lɑɾ əbaʊɾ ɔɹtʃɝdz. oʊ, hi hæd plæntəɾ ə fju tʃɹiz bæk ɑn ɪz fɑɹm ɪn ændɝ. hu dɪdn əv ə tʃɹi əɹ tu tə fɪl ɪn speɪs ɑn ðə dɪnɝ teɪbəl? hid plæntəɾ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɔlnʌt tʃɹiz ɑn ðə deɪ hid mɛɹiɾ ɑdʒɹɪn. ɪt hæd fɛlt ɡʊd tə hæv əɹ tʃɹiz ðɛɹ, aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz wɪndoʊ, æftɝ ʃid daɪd.

Almen Bunt didn't know a lot about orchards. Oh, he had planted a few trees back on his farm in Andor. Who didn't have a tree or two to fill in space on the dinner table? He'd planted a pair of walnut trees on the day he'd married Adrinne. It had felt good to have her trees there, outside his window, after she'd died.

ɹʌnɪŋ ən ɔɹtʃɝd wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli. ðəɹ wɝ nɪɹli θɹi hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹiz ɪn ðɪs fild. ɪt wɑz ɪz sɪstɝz ɔɹtʃɝd; hi wɑz vɪzəɾɪŋ waɪl ɪz sʌnz mænədʒd ɪz fɑɹm nɪɹ kɛɹisfɝd.

Running an orchard was something else entirely. There were nearly three hundred trees in this field. It was his sister's orchard; he was visiting while his sons managed his farm near Carysford.

ɪn ɪz ʃɝt pɑkət, ɑlmɛn kæɹiɾ ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ɪz sʌnz. ə dɛspɹɪt lɛɾɝ, pliɾɪŋ fəɹ hɛlp, bʌɾ i kʊdnt ɡoʊ tə ðɛm. hi wɑz niɾəd hɪɹ.

In his shirt pocket, Almen carried a letter from his sons. A desperate letter, pleading for help, but he couldn't go to them. He was needed here.

bɪsaɪdz, ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd taɪm fəɹ ɪm tə bi aʊɾ ʌv ændɝ. hi wɑz ə kwinz mæn. ðəɹ hæd bɪn taɪmz, ɹisənli, wən biɪŋ ə kwinz mæn kəd ɡɛt sʌmwʌn ɪndə əz mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl əz hævɪŋ wʌn tu mɛni kaʊz ɪn ɪz pæstʃɝ.

Besides, it was a good time for him to be out of Andor. He was a Queen's man. There had been times, recently, when being a Queen's man could get someone into as much trouble as having one too many cows in his pasture.

"wʌt də wi du, ɑlmɛn?" æɾɪm æskt. "ðoʊz tʃɹiz, ðeɪ . . . wɛl, ɪɾ eɪn səpoʊz tə hæpən laɪk ðɪs." ðə bɔɪ ʌv θɝtin hæd ɡoʊldən hɛɹ fɹəm ɪz fɑðɝz saɪd.

"What do we do, Almen?" Adim asked. "Those trees, they . . . Well, it ain't supposed to happen like this." The boy of thirteen had golden hair from his father's side.

ɑlmɛn ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn, skɹætʃɪŋ əɾ ə pætʃ ʌv wɪskɝz hid mɪs dʊɹɪŋ ʃeɪvɪŋ. hɑn, æɾɪmz oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ, əpɹoʊtʃt ðɛm. ðə læd hæd kɑɹvd ɑlmɛn ə sɛɾ ʌv wʊɾən tiθ əz ən ɝaɪvəl ɡɪft ɝliɝ ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ. wʌnʒɹəs θɪŋz, hɛl təɡɛðɝ baɪ waɪɝz, wɪð ɡæps fəɹ ðə fju ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tiθ i hæd. bʌɾ ɪf i tʃud tu hɑɹd, ðeɪd ɡoʊ ɔl aʊɾ ə ʃeɪp.

Almen rubbed his chin, scratching at a patch of whiskers he'd missed during shaving. Hahn, Adim's older brother, approached them. The lad had carved Almen a set of wooden teeth as an arrival gift earlier in the spring. Wondrous things, held together by wires, with gaps for the few remaining teeth he had. But if he chewed too hard, they'd go all out of shape.

ðə ɹoʊz ə tʃɹiz wɝ stʃɹeɪɾ ən pɝfəkli speɪst. ɡɹɛɡɝ - ɑlmɛn ɛs bɹʌðɝ-ɪn-lɔ - ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn mətɪkjələs. bʌɾ i wɑz dɛd naʊ, wɪtʃ wɑz waɪ ɑlmɛn hæd kʌm. ðə nit ɹoʊz ə tʃɹiz kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn fəɹ spænz ən spænz, kɛɹfəli pɹund, fɝɾəlaɪzd, ən wɔɾɝd.

The rows of trees were straight and perfectly spaced. Graeger - Almen s brother-in-law - always had been meticulous. But he was dead now, which was why Almen had come. The neat rows of trees continued on for spans and spans, carefully pruned, fertilized, and watered.

ən dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt, ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl wʌn ə ðɛm hæd ʃɛd ðɛɹ fɹut. taɪni æpəlz, bɛɹli əz lɑɹdʒ əz ə mænz θʌm. θaʊzənz ə ðɛm. ðeɪd ʃɹɪvəl dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt, ðən fɔlən. ən ɪntaɪɝ kɹɑp, ɡɔn.

And during the night, every single one of them had shed their fruit. Tiny apples, barely as large as a man's thumb. Thousands of them. They'd shriveled during the night, then fallen. An entire crop, gone.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə seɪ, lædz," ɑlmɛn faɪnəli ədmɪɾəd.

"I don't know what to say, lads," Almen finally admitted.

"ju, əɾ ə lɔs fəɹ wɝdz?" hɑn sɛd. æɾɪmz bɹʌðɝ hæd dɑɹkɝ kʌlɝɪŋ, laɪk ɪz mʌðɝ, ən wɑz tɔl fəɹ ɪz fɪftin jɪɹz. "ʌŋkəl, jə juʒəwəli hæv əz mʌtʃ tə seɪ əz ə ɡlimən huz bɪn ət ðə bɹændi fəɹ hæf ðə naɪt!" hɑn laɪk tə meɪnteɪn ə stʃɹɔŋ fɹʌn fəɹ ɪz bɹʌðɝ, naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz ðə mæn ə ðə fæmli. bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə bi wɝid.

"You, at a loss for words?" Hahn said. Adim's brother had darker coloring, like his mother, and was tall for his fifteen years. "Uncle, you usually have as much to say as a gleeman who's been at the brandy for half the night!" Hahn liked to maintain a strong front for his brother, now that he was the man of the family. But sometimes it was good to be worried.

ən ɑlmɛn wɑz wɝid. vɛɹi wɝid.

And Almen was worried. Very worried.

"wi bɛɹli hæv ə wiks ɡɹeɪn lɛft," æɾɪm sɛd sɔfli. "ænd wʌt wiv ɡɑt, wi ɡɑt baɪ pɹɑməsəz ɑn ðə kɹɑp. noʊbɑdi wɪl ɡɪv əs ɛniθɪŋ, naʊ. noʊbɑdi hæz ɛniθɪŋ."

"We barely have a week's grain left," Adim said softly. "And what we've got, we got by promises on the crop. Nobody will give us anything, now. Nobody has anything."

ði ɔɹtʃɝd wɑz wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒəs pɹədusɝz ɪn ðə ɹidʒən; hæf ðə mɛn ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ wɝkt ɪt dʊɹɪŋ wʌn steɪdʒ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ðeɪ wɝ dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ɪt. ðeɪ niɾəd ɪt. wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ fud ɡoʊɪŋ bæd, wɪð ðɛɹ stɔɹz juzd ʌp dʊɹɪŋ ði ənnætʃɹəl wɪntɝ . . .

The orchard was one of the largest producers in the region; half the men in the village worked it during one stage or another. They were depending on it. They needed it. With so much food going bad, with their stores used up during the unnatural winter . . .

ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ði ɪnsəɾənt ðət hæd kɪld ɡɹɛɡɝ. ðə mæn hæd wɔkt ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ oʊvɝ ɪn nɛdʒɪn bɹɪdʒ ən vænɪʃt. wən pipəl wɛn lʊkɪŋ, ɔl ðeɪ faʊnd wɑz ə twɪstəd, lifləs tʃɹi wɪð ə ɡɹeɪ-waɪt tʃɹʌŋk ðət smɛld ə sʌlfɝ.

And then there was the incident that had killed Graeger. The man had walked around a corner over in Negin Bridge and vanished. When people went looking, all they found was a twisted, leafless tree with a gray-white trunk that smelled of sulphur.

ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ hæd bɪn skɹɔld ɑn ə fju dɔɹz ðət naɪt. pipəl wɝ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ nɝvəs. wʌns, ɑlmɛn wʊɾə neɪmd əm ɔl fulz, dʒʌmpɪŋ ət ʃædoʊz ən siɪŋ blʌɾi tʃɹɑləks ʌndɝ ɛvɹi kɑbəlstoʊn.

The Dragon's Fang had been scrawled on a few doors that night. People were more and more nervous. Once, Almen would have named them all fools, jumping at shadows and seeing bloody Trollocs under every cobblestone.

naʊ . . . wɛl, naʊ hi wɑzn soʊ ʃʊɹ. hi ɡlænst istwɝd, təwɔɹd tɑɹ vəlɑn. kəd ðə wɪtʃəz bi tə bleɪm fəɹ ðə feɪl kɹɑp? hi heɪɾəd biɪŋ soʊ kloʊs tə ðɛɹ nɛst, bʌɾ ælɪsə niɾəd ðə hɛlp.

Now . . . well, now he wasn't so sure. He glanced eastward, toward Tar Valon. Could the witches be to blame for the failed crop? He hated being so close to their nest, but Alysa needed the help.

ðeɪd tʃɑp daʊn ðət tʃɹi ən bɝn ɪt. jə kəd stɪl smɛl bɹɪmstoʊn ɪn ðə skwɛɹ.

They'd chopped down that tree and burned it. You could still smell brimstone in the square.

"ʌŋkəl?" hɑn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. "wʌt . . . wʌt də wi du?"

"Uncle?" Hahn said, sounding uncomfortable. "What . . . what do we do?"

"aɪ . . ." wʌd ðeɪ du? "bɝn mi, bʌt wi ʃəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ tə keɪɛmlɪn. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðə nu kwin əz ɛvɹiθɪŋ klɪɹɾ ʌp ðəɹ baɪ naʊ. wi kən ɡɛt mi sɛɾəld ɹaɪt baɪ ðə lɔ. hu ɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ, ɡeɪnɪŋ ə pɹaɪs ɑn jəɹ hɛd fəɹ spikɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn feɪvɝ ə ðə kwin?" hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz ɹæmblɪŋ. ðə bɔɪz kɛp lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm.

"I . . ." What did they do? "Burn me, but we should all go to Caemlyn. I'm sure the new Queen has everything cleared up there by now. We can get me settled right by the law. Who ever heard of such a thing, gaining a price on your head for speaking out in favor of the Queen?" He realized he was rambling. The boys kept looking at him.

"noʊ," ɑlmɛn kəntɪnjud. "bɝn mi, bɔɪz, bʌt ðæts ɹɔŋ. wi kænt ɡoʊ. wi nid tə kip ɑn wɝkɪŋ. ðɪs ɪzən ɛni wɝs ðən wən aɪ lɔs maɪ ɪntaɪɝ mɪlət fil tə ə leɪt fɹɔs twɛnti jɪɹz bæk.

"No," Almen continued. "Burn me, boys, but that's wrong. We can't go. We need to keep on working. This isn't any worse than when I lost my entire millet field to a late frost twenty years back.

wɪl ɡɛt θɹu ðɪs, ɹaɪɾ əz laɪt wi wɪl."

We'll get through this, right as Light we will."

ðə tʃɹiz ðɛmsɛlvz lʊk faɪn. nɑɾ ən ɪnsɛk baɪɾ ɑn ðɛm, livz ə lɪɾəl jɛloʊd, bʌt stɪl ɡʊd. ʃʊɹ, ðə spɹɪŋ bʌdz hæd kʌm leɪt, ən ði æpəlz hæd ɡɹoʊn sloʊli. bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɡɹoʊɪŋ.

The trees themselves looked fine. Not an insect bite on them, leaves a little yellowed, but still good. Sure, the spring buds had come late, and the apples had grown slowly. But they had been growing.

"hɑn," ɑlmɛn faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ. "ju noʊ jəɹ fɑðɝz fɛlɪŋ æks əz ðoʊz tʃɪps ɑn ɪt?

"Hahn," Almen found himself saying. "You know your father's felling axe has those chips on it?

waɪ doʊn jə ɡoʊ əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪt ʃɑɹpənd? æɾɪm, ɡoʊ fɛtʃ ʌsoʊ ən mʊɹ ən ðɛɹ kɑɹts. wɪl sɔɹt θɹu ðoʊz fɔlən æpəlz ən si ɪf ɛni ɑɹən ɹɑɾɪd tu bædli. meɪbi ðə pɪɡz wɪl teɪk ðɛm." ət lis ðeɪ stɪl hæd tu. bʌt ðɛɹəd bɪn noʊ paɪɡələts ðɪs spɹɪŋ.

Why don't you go about getting it sharpened? Adim, go fetch Uso and Moor and their carts. We'll sort through those fallen apples and see if any aren't rotted too badly. Maybe the pigs will take them." At least they still had two. But there'd been no piglets this spring.

ðə juðz hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

The youths hesitated.

"ɡoʊ ɑn naʊ," ɑlmɛn sɛd. "noʊ jus dæliɪŋ kəz wiv hæɾ ə sɛtbæk."

"Go on now," Almen said. "No use dallying because we've had a setback."

ðə lædz heɪsən ɔf, oʊbiɾiənt. aɪɾəl hænz meɪɾ aɪɾəl maɪnz. səm wɝk wəd kip əm fɹəm θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌt wɑz tə kʌm.

The lads hastened off, obedient. Idle hands made idle minds. Some work would keep them from thinking about what was to come.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɛlpɪŋ ðət fəɹ hɪm. hi lin daʊn ɑn ðə fɛns, filɪŋ ðə ɹʌf ɡɹuvz ə ði ənsəndɪd plæŋks ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹmz. ðət wɪn tʌɡd ət ðə teɪlz ə hɪz ʃɝɾ əɡɛn; ɑdʒɹɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz fɔɹst ɪm tə tʌk ɪɾ ɪn, bʌt naʊ ðət ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, hi . . . wɛl, hi nɛvɝ hæd laɪkt wɛɹɪŋ ɪt ðət weɪ.

There was no helping that for him. He leaned down on the fence, feeling the rough grooves of the unsanded planks under his arms. That wind tugged at the tails of his shirt again; Adrinne had always forced him to tuck it in, but now that she was gone, he . . . well, he never had liked wearing it that way.

hi tʌk ðə ʃɝɾ ɪn ɛniweɪ.

He tucked the shirt in anyway.

ði ɛɹ smɛld ɹɔŋ sʌmhaʊ. steɪl, laɪk ði ɛɹ ɪnsaɪɾ ə sɪɾi. flaɪz wɝ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə bʌz ɝaʊn ðə ʃɹɪvəl bɪts ðət hæd wʌns bɪn æpəlz.

The air smelled wrong somehow. Stale, like the air inside a city. Flies were starting to buzz around the shriveled bits that had once been apples.

ɑlmɛn hæd lɪvd ə lɔŋ taɪm. hid nɛvɝ kɛp kaʊnt; ɑdʒɹɪn hæd dʌn ðət fəɹ hɪm. ɪt wɑzn ɪmpɔɹɾənt. hi nu hid sin ə lɑɾ ə jɪɹz, ən ðət wɑz ðæt.

Almen had lived a long time. He'd never kept count; Adrinne had done that for him. It wasn't important. He knew he'd seen a lot of years, and that was that.

hid sin ɪnsɛks ətæk ə kɹɑp; hid sin plæns lɔs tə flʌd, tə dʒɹaʊt, əɹ tə nɛɡlədʒəns. bʌɾ ɪn ɔl ɪz jɪɹz, hid nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs. ðɪs wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ivəl. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stɑɹvɪŋ. ðeɪ dɪdn tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt, nɑt wən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əɹ juðz wɝ ɝaʊnd. ði ədʌls kwaɪətli ɡeɪv wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə ðə jʌŋ ən tə wɪmən u wɝ nɝsɪŋ. bʌt ðə kaʊz wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ dʒɹaɪ, ðə stɔɹz spɔɪlɪŋ, ðə kɹɑps daɪɪŋ.

He'd seen insects attack a crop; he'd seen plants lost to flood, to drought, or to negligence. But in all his years, he'd never seen anything like this. This was something evil. The village was already starving. They didn't talk about it, not when the children or youths were around. The adults quietly gave what they had to the young and to women who were nursing. But the cows were going dry, the stores spoiling, the crops dying.

ðə lɛɾɝ ɪn ɪz pɑkət sɛɾ ɪz oʊn fɑɹm hæd bɪn sɛɾ əpɑn baɪ pæsɪŋ mɝsənɛɹiz. ðeɪ hædn hɑɹmd ɛniwʌn, bʌt ðeɪd teɪkən ɛvɹi skɹæp ə fud. hɪz sʌnz sɝvaɪvd oʊnli baɪ dɪɡɪŋ hæf-ɡɹoʊn pəteɪɾoʊz fɹəm ðə kɹɑp ən bɔɪlɪŋ ðɛm. ðeɪ faʊnd naɪntin aʊɾ ʌv ɛvɹi twɛnti ɹɑɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɪnɪksplɪkəbli fʊl ʌv wɝmz dɪspaɪt ɡɹin ɡɹoʊθ əbʌv.

The letter in his pocket said his own farm had been set upon by passing mercenaries. They hadn't harmed anyone, but they'd taken every scrap of food. His sons survived only by digging half-grown potatoes from the crop and boiling them. They found nineteen out of every twenty rotting in the ground, inexplicably full of worms despite green growth above.

dʌzənz ə nɪɹbaɪ vɪlədʒəz wɝ sʌfɝɪŋ ðə seɪm weɪ. noʊ fud tə bi hæd. tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪtsɛlf wɑz hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl fiɾɪŋ ɪts pipəl.

Dozens of nearby villages were suffering the same way. No food to be had. Tar Valon itself was having trouble feeding its people.

stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ðoʊz nit, pɝfəkt ɹoʊz ə jusləs æpəl tʃɹiz, ɑlmɛn fɛl ðə kɹʌʃɪŋ weɪɾ ʌv ɪt.

Staring down those neat, perfect rows of useless apple trees, Almen felt the crushing weight of it.

ʌv tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪmeɪn pɑzəɾɪv. ʌv siɪŋ ɔl ɪz sɪstɝ hæd wɝk fəɹ feɪl ən ɹɑt. ðiz æpəlz . . .

Of trying to remain positive. Of seeing all his sister had worked for fail and rot. These apples . . .

ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə hæv seɪv ðə vɪlədʒ, ən ɪz sʌnz.

they were supposed to have saved the village, and his sons.

hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld. ɪt dɪd ðəɾ ə lɑt leɪtli.

His stomach rumbled. It did that a lot lately.

ðɪs ɪz ɪt ðɛn, ɪzən ɪt? hi θɔt, aɪz təwɔɹd ðə tu-jɛloʊ ɡɹæs bɪloʊ. ðə faɪt dʒʌst ɛndəd.

This is it then, isn't it? he thought, eyes toward the too-yellow grass below. The fight just ended.

ɑlmɛn slʌmp daʊn, filɪŋ ə weɪɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ɑdʒɹɪn, hi θɔt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə taɪm wən hid bɪn kwɪk tə læf, kwɪk tə tɔk. naʊ hi fɛlt wɔɹn, laɪk ə poʊs ðət hæd bɪn sændɪɾ ən sændɪɾ ən sændɪɾ əntɪl oʊnli ə slɪvɝ wɑz lɛft. meɪbi ɪt wɑz taɪm tə lɛt ɡoʊ.

Almen slumped down, feeling a weight on his shoulders. Adrinne, he thought. There had been a time when he'd been quick to laugh, quick to talk. Now he felt worn, like a post that had been sanded and sanded and sanded until only a sliver was left. Maybe it was time to let go.

hi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ɪz nɛk. wɔɹmθ.

He felt something on his neck. Warmth.

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən tɝnd wɪɹi aɪz təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ. sʌnlaɪt beɪðd ɪz feɪs. hi ɡeɪpt; ɪt sim soʊ lɔŋ sɪns hid sin pjʊɹ sʌnlaɪt. ɪt ʃoʊn daʊn θɹu ə lɑɹdʒ bɹeɪk ɪn ðə klaʊdz, kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, laɪk ðə wɔɹmθ ʌv ən ʌvən beɪkɪŋ ə loʊf ʌv ɑdʒɹɪnz θɪk saʊɝɾoʊ bɹɛd.

He hesitated, then turned weary eyes toward the sky. Sunlight bathed his face. He gaped; it seemed so long since he'd seen pure sunlight. It shone down through a large break in the clouds, comforting, like the warmth of an oven baking a loaf of Adrinne's thick sourdough bread.

ɑlmɛn stʊd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə ʃeɪɾ ɪz aɪz. hi tʊk ə dip, lɔŋ bɹɛθ, ən smɛld . . . æpəl blɑsəmz? hi spʌn wɪð ə stɑɹt.

Almen stood, raising a hand to shade his eyes. He took a deep, long breath, and smelled . . . apple blossoms? He spun with a start.

ði æpəl tʃɹiz wɝ flaʊɝɪŋ.

The apple trees were flowering.

ðət wɑz pleɪn ɹɪdɪkjələs. hi ɹʌbd ɪz aɪz, bʌt ðət dɪdn dɪspɛl ði ɪmədʒ. ðeɪ wɝ blumɪŋ, ɔl ə ðɛm, waɪt flaʊɝz bɹeɪkɪŋ aʊt bɪtwin ðə livz. ðə flaɪz bʌzd ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən zɪpt əweɪ ɑn ðə wɪnd. ðə dɑɹk bɪts ʌv æpəl ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn mɛltəɾ əweɪ, laɪk wæks bɪfɔɹ ə fleɪm. ɪn sɛkənz, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ə ðɛm, nɑɾ ivən dʒus. ðə ɡɹaʊn hæɾ əbzɔɹb ðɛm.

That was plain ridiculous. He rubbed his eyes, but that didn't dispel the image. They were blooming, all of them, white flowers breaking out between the leaves. The flies buzzed into the air and zipped away on the wind. The dark bits of apple on the ground melted away, like wax before a flame. In seconds, there was nothing left of them, not even juice. The ground had absorbed them.

wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ? æpəl tʃɹiz dɪdn blɑsəm twaɪs. wɑz i ɡoʊɪŋ mæd?

What was happening? Apple trees didn't blossom twice. Was he going mad?

fʊtstɛps saʊndəd sɔfli ɑn ðə pæθ ðət ɹæn pæs ði ɔɹtʃɝd. ɑlmɛn spʌn tə faɪn ə tɔl jʌŋ mæn wɔkɪŋ daʊn aʊɾ ə ðə fʊthɪlz. hi hæd dip ɹɛd hɛɹ ən i wɔɹ ɹæɡəd kloʊðɪŋ: ə bɹaʊn kloʊk wɪð lus slivz ən ə sɪmpəl waɪt lɪnən ʃɝt bɪniθ. ðə tʃɹaʊzɝz wɝ faɪnɝ, blæk wɪð ə dɛləkəɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ʌv ɡoʊld ət ðə kʌf.

Footsteps sounded softly on the path that ran past the orchard. Almen spun to find a tall young man walking down out of the foothills. He had deep red hair and he wore ragged clothing: a brown cloak with loose sleeves and a simple white linen shirt beneath. The trousers were finer, black with a delicate embroidery of gold at the cuff.

"hoʊ, stʃɹeɪnʒɝ," ɑlmɛn sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hænd, nɑt noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɛls tə seɪ, nɑɾ ivən ʃʊɹ ɪf hid sin wʌɾ i θɔt hid sin. "dɪd jə . . . dɪd jə ɡɛt lɔst ʌp ɪn ðə fʊthɪlz?"

"Ho, stranger," Almen said, raising a hand, not knowing what else to say, not even sure if he'd seen what he thought he'd seen. "Did you . . . did you get lost up in the foothills?"

ðə mæn stɑpt, tɝnɪŋ ʃɑɹpli. hi sim sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɑlmɛn ðɛɹ. wɪð ə stɑɹt, ɑlmɛn ɹilaɪz ðə mænz lɛft ɑɹm ɛndəɾ ɪn ə stʌmp.

The man stopped, turning sharply. He seemed surprised to find Almen there. With a start, Almen realized the man's left arm ended in a stump.

ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ lʊkt əbaʊt, ðən bɹiðd ɪn dipli. "noʊ. aɪm nɑt lɔst. faɪnəli. ɪt filz laɪk ə ɡɹeɪt lɔŋ taɪm sɪns aɪv ʌndɝstʊd ðə pæθ bɪfɔɹ mi."

The stranger looked about, then breathed in deeply. "No. I'm not lost. Finally. It feels like a great long time since I've understood the path before me."

ɑlmɛn skɹætʃt ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz feɪs. bɝn hɪm, ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ pætʃ hid mɪst ʃeɪvɪŋ. hɪz hæn hæd bɪn ʃeɪkɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ ðəɾ i maɪɾ əz wɛl əv skɪp ðə ɹeɪzɝ ɪntaɪɝli. "nɑt lɔst? sʌn, ðət pæθweɪ oʊnli lidz ʌp ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ði ɛɹiəz bɪn hʌntəd klin, ɪf jə wɝ hoʊpɪŋ tə faɪn səm ɡeɪm. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ bæk ðəɹ ə jus."

Almen scratched the side of his face. Burn him, there was another patch he'd missed shaving. His hand had been shaking so much that he might as well have skipped the razor entirely. "Not lost? Son, that pathway only leads up the slopes of Dragonmount. The area's been hunted clean, if you were hoping to find some game. There's nothing back there of use."

"aɪ wʊdn seɪ ðæt," ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz θɪŋz ə jus ɝaʊnd, ɪf jə lʊk kloʊsli ɪnʌf. jə kæn stɛɹ əɾ əm tu lɔŋ. tə lɝn bʌt nɑt bi oʊvɝwɛlmd, ðəɾ ɪz ðə bæləns."

"I wouldn't say that," the stranger said, glancing over his shoulder. "There are always things of use around, if you look closely enough. You can't stare at them too long. To learn but not be overwhelmed, that is the balance."

ɑlmɛn foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz. ðə mænz wɝdz ... ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ hævɪŋ tu dɪfɹən kɑnvɝseɪʃənz. pɝhæps ðə læd wɑzn ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə mæn, ðoʊ.

Almen folded his arms. The man's words ... it seemed they were having two different conversations. Perhaps the lad wasn't right in the head. There was something about the man, though.

ðə weɪ hi stʊd, ðə weɪ ðoʊz aɪz ə hɪz stɛɹd wɪð sətʃ kɑm ɪntɛnsəɾi. ɑlmɛn fɛlt laɪk stændɪŋ ʌp ən dʌstɪŋ ɔf ɪz ʃɝt tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf mɔɹ pɹəzɛntəbəl.

The way he stood, the way those eyes of his stared with such calm intensity. Almen felt like standing up and dusting off his shirt to make himself more presentable.

"du aɪ noʊ ju?" ɑlmɛn æskt. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə jʌŋ mæn wɑz fəmɪljɝ.

"Do I know you?" Almen asked. Something about the young man was familiar.

"jɛs," ðə læd sɛd. ðən i nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ði ɔɹtʃɝd. "ɡæðɝ jəɹ pipəl ən kəlɛk ðoʊz æpəlz. ðəl bi niɾəd ɪn ðə deɪz tə kʌm."

"Yes," the lad said. Then he nodded toward the orchard. "Gather your people and collect those apples. They'll be needed in the days to come."

"ði æpəlz?" ɑlmɛn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ. "bʌt - " hi fɹoʊz. ðə tʃɹiz wɝ bɝdʒənɪŋ wɪð nu, ɹaɪp ɹɛɾ æpəlz. ðə blɑsəmz hid sin ɝliɝ hæd fɔlən fɹi, ən blæŋkəɾɪd ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn waɪt, laɪk snoʊ.

"The apples?" Almen said, turning. "But - " He froze. The trees were burgeoning with new, ripe red apples. The blossoms he'd seen earlier had fallen free, and blanketed the ground in white, like snow.

ðoʊz æpəlz sim tə ʃaɪn. nɑt dʒʌs dʌzənz ə ðɛm ɑn itʃ tʃɹi, bʌt hʌnʒɹədz. mɔɹ ðən ə tʃɹi ʃəd hoʊld, itʃ wʌn pɝfəkli ɹaɪp.

Those apples seemed to shine. Not just dozens of them on each tree, but hundreds. More than a tree should hold, each one perfectly ripe.

"aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ mæd," ɑlmɛn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðə mæn.

"I am going mad," Almen said, turning back to the man.

"ɪts nɑt jə hu ɪz mæd, fɹɛnd," ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ sɛd. "bʌt ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld. ɡæðɝ ðoʊz æpəlz kwɪkli. maɪ pɹɛzəns wɪl hoʊld ɪm ɔf fəɹ ə taɪm, aɪ θɪŋk, ən wʌtɛvɝ jə teɪk naʊ ʃəd bi seɪf fɹəm ɪz tʌtʃ."

"It's not you who is mad, friend," the stranger said. "But the entire world. Gather those apples quickly. My presence will hold him off for a time, I think, and whatever you take now should be safe from his touch."

ðət vɔɪs . . . ðoʊz aɪz, laɪk ɡɹeɪ dʒɛmstoʊnz kʌɾ ən sɛɾ ɪn ɪz feɪs. "aɪ də noʊ ju," ɑlmɛn sɛd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ən ɑd pɛɹ ə juðz i hæd ɡɪvən ə lɪft ɪn ɪz kɑɹt jɪɹz əɡoʊ. "laɪt! jəɹ hɪm, ɑɹən ju? ðə wʌn ðəɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?"

That voice . . . Those eyes, like gray gemstones cut and set in his face. "I do know you," Almen said, remembering an odd pair of youths he had given a lift in his cart years ago. "Light! You're him, aren't you? The one they're talking about?"

ðə mæn lʊk bæk əɾ ɑlmɛn. miɾɪŋ ðoʊz aɪz, ɑlmɛn fɛlt ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɛns ə pis. "ɪɾ ɪz laɪkli," ðə mæn sɛd. "mɛn ɑɹ ɔfən spikɪŋ ə mi." hi smaɪld, ðən tɝn ən kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn ɪz weɪ daʊn ðə pæθ.

The man looked back at Almen. Meeting those eyes, Almen felt a strange sense of peace. "It is likely," the man said. "Men are often speaking of me." He smiled, then turned and continued on his way down the path.

"weɪt," ɑlmɛn sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn təwɔɹd ðə mæn u kəɾ oʊnli bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

"Wait," Almen said, raising a hand toward the man who could only be the Dragon Reborn.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?"

"Where are you going?"

ðə mæn lʊk bæk wɪð ə feɪnt ɡɹɪmɑs. "tə də sʌmθɪŋ aɪv bɪn pʊɾɪŋ ɔf. aɪ daʊt ʃɪl bi pliz baɪ wʌɾ aɪ tɛl hɝ."

The man looked back with a faint grimace. "To do something I've been putting off. I doubt she will be pleased by what I tell her."

ɑlmɛn loʊɝɾ ɪz hænd, wɑtʃɪŋ əz ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, daʊn ə pæθweɪ bɪtwin tu fɛnst ɔɹtʃɝdz, tʃɹiz leɪɾən wɪð blʌd-ɹɛɾ æpəlz. ɑlmɛn θɔt - fəɹ ə moʊmənt - hi kəd si sʌmθɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə mæn. ə laɪtnəs tə ði ɛɹ, wɔɹpt ən bɛnt.

Almen lowered his hand, watching as the stranger strode away, down a pathway between two fenced orchards, trees laden with blood-red apples. Almen thought - for a moment - he could see something around the man. A lightness to the air, warped and bent.

ɑlmɛn wɑtʃt ðə mæn əntɪl i vænɪʃt, ðən dæʃt təwɔɹɾ ælɪsəz haʊs. ði oʊl peɪn ɪn ɪz hɪp wɑz ɡɔn, ən i fɛlt əz ɪf i kəd ɹʌn ə dʌzən liɡz. hæfweɪ tə ðə haʊs, hi mɛɾ æɾɪm ən ðə tu wɝkɝz kʌmɪŋ tə ði ɔɹtʃɝd. ðeɪ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð kənsɝn aɪz əz i pʊl tə ə hɔlt.

Almen watched the man until he vanished, then dashed toward Alysa's house. The old pain in his hip was gone, and he felt as if he could run a dozen leagues. Halfway to the house, he met Adim and the two workers coming to the orchard. They regarded him with concerned eyes as he pulled to a halt.

əneɪbəl tə spik, ɑlmɛn tɝn ən pɔɪntəd bæk ət ði ɔɹtʃɝdz. ði æpəlz wɝ ɹɛd spɛks, dɑɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹin laɪk fɹɛkəlz.

Unable to speak, Almen turned and pointed back at the orchards. The apples were red specks, dotting the green like freckles.

"wʌts ðæt?" ʌsoʊ æskt, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ feɪs. mʊɹ skwɪntɪd, ðən bɪɡæn ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd ði ɔɹtʃɝd.

"What's that?" Uso asked, rubbing his long face. Moor squinted, then began running toward the orchard.

"ɡæðɝ ɛvɹiwʌn," ɑlmɛn sɛd, wɪndɪd. "ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ, fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒəz nɪɹbaɪ, pipəl pæsɪŋ ɑn ʃaɪmənz ɹoʊd. ɛvɹiwʌn. ɡɛɾ əm hɪɹ tə ɡæðɝ ən pɪk."

"Gather everyone," Almen said, winded. "Everyone from the village, from the villages nearby, people passing on Shyman's road. Everyone. Get them here to gather and pick."

"pɪk wʌt?" æɾɪm æskt wɪð ə fɹaʊn.

"Pick what?" Adim asked with a frown.

"æpəlz," ɑlmɛn sɛd. "wʌɾ ɛls blʌɾi ɡɹoʊz ɑn æpəl tʃɹiz! lɪsən, wi niɾ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz æpəlz pɪk bɪfɔɹ ðə deɪ ɛnz. jə hɪɹ mi? ɡoʊ! spɹɛd ðə wɝd! ðɛɹz ə hɑɹvəst æftɝ ɔl!"

"Apples," Almen said. "What else bloody grows on apple trees! Listen, we need every one of those apples picked before the day ends. You hear me? Go! Spread the word! There's a harvest after all!"

ðeɪ ɹæn ɔf tə lʊk, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bleɪm əm fəɹ ðæt. ɑlmɛn kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn, ən əz i dɪd, hi noʊɾəst fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðət ðə ɡɹæs ɝaʊn ɪm simd ɡɹinɝ, hɛlθiɝ.

They ran off to look, of course. It was hard to blame them for that. Almen continued on, and as he did, he noticed for the first time that the grass around him seemed greener, healthier.

hi lʊkt istwɝd. ɑlmɛn fɛlt ə pʊl ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz tʌɡɪŋ ɪm sɔfli ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ hæd ɡɔn.

He looked eastward. Almen felt a pull inside of him. Something was tugging him softly in the direction the stranger had gone.

æpəlz fɝst, hi θɔt. ðən . . . wɛl, ðən hid si.

Apples first, he thought. Then . . . well, then he'd see.


tʃæptɝ tu


CHAPTER 2

kwɛstʃənz ə liɾɝʃɪp


Questions of Leadership

θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld əbʌv, sɑft ən mɛnəsɪŋ laɪk ðə ɡɹaʊl ʌv ə dɪstən bist. pɛɹɪn tɝn ɪz aɪz təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ. ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ, ðə pɝveɪsɪv klaʊd kʌvɝ hæd tɝn blæk, dɑɹkənɪŋ laɪk ði ædvɛn ʌv ə hɔɹəbəl stɔɹm. bʌt ɹeɪn hæd kʌm oʊnli ɪn spɝts.

Thunder rumbled above, soft and menacing like the growl of a distant beast. Perrin turned his eyes toward the sky. A few days ago, the pervasive cloud cover had turned black, darkening like the advent of a horrible storm. But rain had come only in spurts.

ənʌðɝ ɹʌmbəl ʃʊk ði ɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ laɪtnɪŋ. pɛɹɪn pæɾəd steɪɝ ɑn ðə nɛk; ðə hɔɹs smɛl skɪɾɪʃ - pɹɪkli, swɛɾi. ðə hɔɹs wɑzn ði oʊnli wʌn. ðət sɛn hʌŋ əbʌv ɪz ɪnɔɹməs fɔɹs ə tʃɹups ən ɹɛfjudʒiz əz ðeɪ tʃɹæmpt əkɹɔs ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊnd. ðət fɔɹs kɹieɪɾəd ə θʌndɝ ʌv ɪts oʊn, fʊtstɛps, hʊfbits, wæɡən wilz tɝnɪŋ, mɛn ən wɪmən kɔlɪŋ.

Another rumble shook the air. There was no lightning. Perrin patted Stayer on the neck; the horse smelled skittish - prickly, sweaty. The horse wasn't the only one. That scent hung above his enormous force of troops and refugees as they tramped across the muddy ground. That force created a thunder of its own, footsteps, hoofbeats, wagon wheels turning, men and women calling.

ðeɪ hæd nɪɹli ɹitʃt ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd. ɝɪdʒənəli, pɛɹɪn hæd plæn tə kɹɔs ðəɾ ən kəntɪnju ɑn nɔɹθwɝd, təwɔɹɾ ændɝ. bʌt hid lɔst ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm tə ðə sɪknəs ðət hæd stʃɹʌk ɪz kæmp - boʊθ æʃəmən hæd nɪɹli daɪd. ðən ðɪs θɪk mʌd hæd sloʊɾ əm ivən fɝðɝ. ɔl toʊld, ɪt hæd bɪn oʊvɝ ə mʌnθ sɪns ðeɪd lɛf meɪɾən, ən ðeɪd tʃɹævəld oʊnli əz fɑɹ əz pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɝɪdʒənəli hoʊp tə ɡoʊ ɪn ə wik.

They had nearly reached the Jehannah Road. Originally, Perrin had planned to cross that and continue on northward, toward Andor. But he'd lost a great deal of time to the sickness that had struck his camp - both Asha'man had nearly died. Then this thick mud had slowed them even further. All told, it had been over a month since they'd left Maiden, and they'd traveled only as far as Perrin had originally hoped to go in a week.

pɛɹɪn pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət, filɪŋ ət ðə smɔl blæksmɪθs pʌzəl ðɛɹ. ðeɪd faʊn ɪɾ ɪn meɪɾən, ən hid teɪkən tə ɹɪɾəlɪŋ wɪð ɪt. soʊ fɑɹ, hi hædn fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt haʊ tə ɡɛt ðə pisəz əpɑɹt. ɪt wɑz əz kɑmplɛks ə pʌzəl əz hiɾ ɛvɝ sin.

Perrin put his hand into his coat pocket, feeling at the small blacksmith's puzzle there. They'd found it in Maiden, and he'd taken to riddling with it. So far, he hadn't figured out how to get the pieces apart. It was as complex a puzzle as he'd ever seen.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə mæstɝ ɡɪl əɹ ðə pipəl pɛɹɪn hæd sɛn ɑn əhɛd wɪð səplaɪz. ɡɹeɪɾi hæd mænədʒd ə fju smɔl ɡeɪtweɪz əhɛd tə sɛn skaʊts tə faɪn ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ hæd ɹɪtɝnd wɪθaʊt nuz.

There was no sign of Master Gill or the people Perrin had sent on ahead with supplies. Grady had managed a few small gateways ahead to send scouts to find them, but they had returned without news.

pɛɹɪn wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt ðɛm.

Perrin was beginning to worry about them.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ə mæn æskt. hi stʊd bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪnz hɔɹs. tɝn wɑz ə læŋki fɛloʊ wɪð kɝli ɹɛd hɛɹ ən ə bɪɹɾ i taɪɾ ɔf wɪð lɛðɝ kɔɹdz. hi kæɹiɾ ə wɔɹiɝz æks ɪn ə lup əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ə wɪkəd θɪŋ wɪð ə spaɪk ət ðə bæk.

"My Lord?" a man asked. He stood beside Perrin's horse. Turne was a lanky fellow with curly red hair and a beard he tied off with leather cords. He carried a warrior's axe in a loop at his belt, a wicked thing with a spike at the back.

"wi kæn peɪ jə mʌtʃ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ mɛn doʊn əv hɔɹsəz?"

"We can't pay you much," Perrin said. "Your men don't have horses?"

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," tɝn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɪz dʌzən kəmpænjənz. "dʒɹ hæd wʌn. wi eɪɾ ɪɾ ə fju wiks bæk." tɝn smɛld ənwɑʃt ən dɝɾi, ən əbʌv ðoʊz sɛns wɑz ən ɑd steɪlnəs. hæd ðə mænz ɪmoʊʃənz ɡɔn nʌm? "ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd, maɪ lɔɹd. weɪdʒəz kən weɪt. ɪf juv fud . . .

"No, my Lord," Turne said, glancing at his dozen companions. "Jarr had one. We ate it a few weeks back." Turne smelled unwashed and dirty, and above those scents was an odd staleness. Had the man's emotions gone numb? "If you don't mind, my Lord. Wages can wait. If you have food . . .

wɛl, ðət wɪl bi ɪnʌf fəɹ naʊ."

well, that will be enough for now."

/ ʃəd tɝn əm əweɪ, pɛɹɪn θɔt. wi ɔlɹɛɾi hæv tu mɛni maʊðz tə fid. laɪt, hi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɪɾ ə pipəl. bʌt ðiz fɛloʊz lʊk hændi wɪð ðɛɹ wɛpənz, ən ɪf i tɝn əm əweɪ, ðeɪd noʊ daʊt tɝn tə pɪlɪdʒɪŋ.

/ should turn them away, Perrin thought. We already have too many mouths to feed. Light, he was supposed to be getting rid of people. But these fellows looked handy with their weapons, and if he turned them away, they'd no doubt turn to pillaging.

"ɡoʊ wɔk daʊn ðə laɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "faɪn ə mæn neɪm tæm ælθɹ -  hiz ə stɝɾi fɛloʊ, dʒɹɛs laɪk ə fɑɹmɝ. ɛniwʌn ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə pɔɪn jə ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən. tɛl ɪm jə spoʊk tə pɛɹɪn, ən aɪ sɛd tə teɪk jə ɑn fəɹ milz."

"Go walk down the line," Perrin said. "Find a man named Tam al'Thor -  he's a sturdy fellow, dressed like a farmer. Anyone should be able to point you in his direction. Tell him you spoke to Perrin, and I said to take you on for meals."

ðə dɝɾi mɛn ɹɪlækst, ən ðɛɹ læŋki liɾɝ æktʃəli  smɛld ɡɹeɪtfəl. ɡɹeɪtfəl! sɛl-sɔɹdz -  meɪbi bændəts - ɡɹeɪtfəl tə bi teɪkən ɑn oʊnli fəɹ milz. ðət wɑz ðə steɪɾ ə ðə wɝld.

The dirty men relaxed, and their lanky leader actually smelled grateful. Grateful! Sell-swords -  maybe bandits - grateful to be taken on only for meals. That was the state of the world.

"tɛl mi, maɪ lɔɹd," tɝn sɛɾ əz ɪz ɡɹup bɪɡæn tə haɪk daʊn ðə laɪn ə ɹɛfjudʒiz. "du jə ɹɪli hæv fud?"

"Tell me, my Lord," Turne said as his group began to hike down the line of refugees. "Do you really have food?"

"wi du," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ dʒʌst sɛd soʊ."

"We do," Perrin said. "I just said so."

"æn ɪt dʌzn spɔɪl æftɝ ə naɪt lɛft əloʊn?"

"And it doesn't spoil after a night left alone?"

"kɔɹs ɪt dʌznt," pɛɹɪn sɛd stɝnli. "nɑɾ ɪf jə kip ɪt ɹaɪt." səm ə ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪn maɪɾ əv wivəlz ɪn ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɛɾəbəl. ðə mæn sim tə faɪn ðəɾ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl, əz ɪf pɛɹɪn hæd sɛɾ ɪz wæɡənz wəd sun spɹaʊt wɪŋz ən flaɪ ɔf fəɹ ðə maʊntənz.

"Course it doesn't," Perrin said sternly. "Not if you keep it right." Some of their grain might have weevils in it, but it was edible. The man seemed to find that incredible, as if Perrin had said his wagons would soon sprout wings and fly off for the mountains.

"ɡoʊ ɑn naʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn meɪk ʃʊɹ tə tɛl jəɹ mɛn ðət wi ɹʌn ə taɪt kæmp. noʊ faɪɾɪŋ, noʊ stilɪŋ. ɪf aɪ ɡɛɾ ə wɪf ə jə meɪkɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl, jəl bi aʊɾ ɑn jəɹ ɪɹz."

"Go on now," Perrin said. "And make sure to tell your men that we run a tight camp. No fighting, no stealing. If I get a whiff of you making trouble, you'll be out on your ears."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," tɝn sɛd, ðən heɪsən ɔf tə dʒɔɪn ɪz mɛn. hi smɛl sənsɪɹ. tæm wɑzn gɑnə bi pliz tə hæv ənʌðɝ bætʃ ə mɝsənɛɹiz tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ, bʌt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ stɪl aʊt ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ. moʊst ə ðɛm sim tə hæv tɝn istwɝd. bʌt wɪð haʊ sloʊli pɛɹɪnz fɔɹs hæd bɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ, hi wɑz wɝid ði il maɪt tʃeɪnʒ ðɛɹ maɪnz ən kʌm bæk fəɹ hɪm.

"Yes, my Lord," Turne said, then hastened off to join his men. He smelled sincere. Tam wasn't going to be pleased to have another batch of mercenaries to watch over, but the Shaido were still out there somewhere. Most of them seemed to have turned eastward. But with how slowly Perrin's force had been traveling, he was worried the Aiel might change their minds and come back for him.

hi nʌdʒ steɪɝ fɔɹwɝd, flæŋk baɪ ə pɛɹ ə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. naʊ ðəɾ ɛɹæm wɑz ɡɔn, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn hæd - ənfɔɹtʃənətli - teɪkən ɪɾ əpɑn ðɛmsɛlvz tə pɹəvaɪd pɛɹɪn wɪð bɑɾiɡɑɹdz.

He nudged Stayer forward, flanked by a pair of Two Rivers men. Now that Aram was gone, the Two Rivers men had - unfortunately - taken it upon themselves to provide Perrin with bodyguards.

tədeɪz ənɔɪənsɪz wɝ wɪl ælsin ən ɹid soʊələn. pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd tʃuɪŋ aʊt ðə mɛn əbaʊɾ ɪt.

Todays annoyances were Wil al'Seen and Reed Soalen. Perrin had tried chewing out the men about it.

bʌt ðeɪ ɪnsɪstəd, ən i hæd bɪɡɝ wɝiz tə bɑðɝ hɪm, nɑt ðə list ʌv wɪtʃ wɝ ɪz stʃɹeɪnʒ dʒɹimz. hɔntɪŋ vɪʒənz ʌv wɝkɪŋ ðə fɔɹdʒɪz ən biɪŋ əneɪbəl tə kɹieɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv wɝθ.

But they insisted, and he had bigger worries to bother him, not the least of which were his strange dreams. Haunting visions of working the forges and being unable to create anything of worth.

pʊɾ əm aʊɾ ə jəɹ maɪnd, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ðə lɔŋ kɑləm, ælsin ən soʊələn kipɪŋ ʌp. juv naɪtmɛɹz ɪnʌf waɪl əweɪk. dil wɪð ðoʊz fɝst.

Put them out of your mind, he told himself, riding up the long column, al'Seen and Soalen keeping up. You have nightmares enough while awake. Deal with those first.

ðə mɛdoʊ ɝaʊn ɪm wɑz oʊpən, ðoʊ ðə ɡɹæs wɑz jɛloʊɪŋ, ən i noʊɾəst wɪð dɪsplɛʒɝ sɛvɹəl lɑɹdʒ swɑθs ə dɛd waɪldflaʊɹz, ɹɑɾɪŋ. ðə spɹɪŋ ɹeɪnz hæd tɝn moʊst ɛɹiəz laɪk ðɪs ɪndə mʌd tʃɹæps. muvɪŋ soʊ mɛni ɹɛfjudʒiz wɑz sloʊ, ivən dɪskaʊntɪŋ ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl ən ðə mʌd. ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʊk lɔŋɡɝ ðən i ɪkspɛktəd, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə meɪɾən.

The meadow around him was open, though the grass was yellowing, and he noticed with displeasure several large swaths of dead wildflowers, rotting. The spring rains had turned most areas like this into mud traps. Moving so many refugees was slow, even discounting the bubble of evil and the mud. Everything took longer than he expected, including getting out of Maiden.

ðə fɔɹs kɪkt ʌp mʌɾ əz ɪt mɑɹtʃt; moʊst ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz' tʃɹaʊzɝz ən skɝts wɝ kʌvɝd wɪð ɪt, ən ði ɛɹ wɑz θɪk wɪð ɪts stɪki sɛnt. pɛɹɪn nɪɹd ðə fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ laɪn, pæsɪŋ ɹaɪɾɝz ɪn ɹɛd bɹɛstpleɪts, lænsɪz hɛl haɪ, ðɛɹ hɛlmz laɪk ɹɪm pɑts. ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹɾ ə min.

The force kicked up mud as it marched; most of the refugees' trousers and skirts were covered with it, and the air was thick with its sticky scent. Perrin neared the front of their line, passing riders in red breastplates, lances held high, their helms like rimmed pots. The Winged Guard of Mayene.

lɔɹd ɡælɛn ɹoʊɾ ət ðɛɹ fɹʌnt, ɹɛd-plum hɛlm hɛld əɾ ɪz saɪd. hɪz bɛɹɪŋ wɑz fɔɹməl ɪnʌf ðət jə maɪt θɪŋk i wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə pɝeɪd, bʌɾ ɪz sɪŋɡəl aɪ wɑz kin əz i skæn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. hi wɑz ə ɡʊd soʊlʒɝ. ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡʊd soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðɪs fɔɹs, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz tʌf əz bɛndɪŋ ə hɔɹsʃu tə kip ðɛɹ hænz fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts.

Lord Gallenne rode at their front, red-plumed helm held at his side. His bearing was formal enough that you might think he was riding in a parade, but his single eye was keen as he scanned the countryside. He was a good soldier. There were a lot of good soldiers in this force, though sometimes it was tough as bending a horseshoe to keep their hands from one another's throats.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn!" ə vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd. ɑɹɡændə, fɝs kæptən ʌv ɡildən, pʊʃt θɹu ðə minɝ laɪnz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə tɔl ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ. hɪz tʃɹups ɹoʊɾ ɪn ə waɪd kɑləm bɪsaɪd ðə minɝz - ɛvɝ sɪns æliændɝz ɹɪtɝn, ɑɹɡændə hæd bɪn sɛɾ ɑn ikwəl tʃɹitmənt. hid kəmpleɪn ðət ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹɾ ɔfən ɹoʊɾ ɪn fɹʌnt. ɹæðɝ ðən spɝ fɝðɝ ɑɹɡjəməns, pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðɛɹ kɑləmz tə ɹaɪd saɪd baɪ saɪd.

"Lord Perrin!" a voice shouted. Arganda, First Captain of Ghealdan, pushed through the Mayener lines riding a tall roan gelding. His troops rode in a wide column beside the Mayeners - ever since Alliandre's return, Arganda had been set on equal treatment. He'd complained that the Winged Guard often rode in front. Rather than spur further arguments, Perrin had ordered their columns to ride side by side.

"wɑz ðəɾ ənʌðɝ bætʃ ə mɝsənɛɹiz?" ɑɹɡændə dɪmændəd, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ʌp bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn.

"Was that another batch of mercenaries?" Arganda demanded, pulling his horse up beside Perrin.

"ə smɔl bænd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "pɹɑbli wʌns ðə ɡɑɹɾ ə səm loʊkəl sɪɾiz lɔɹd."

"A small band," Perrin said. "Probably once the guard of some local city's lord."

"dɛzɝɾɝz." ɑɹɡændə spæt tə ðə saɪd. "ju ʃʊɾə sɛn fəɹ mi.

"Deserters." Arganda spat to the side. "You should have sent for me.

maɪ kwin wəd wɑn əm stʃɹʌŋ ʌp! doʊn fɝɡɛt ðət wɝ ɪn ɡil-dæn naʊ."

My queen would want them strung up! Don't forget that we're in Gheal-dan now."

"jɔɹ kwin ɪz maɪ laɪdʒwʊmən," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɑləm. "wɝ nɑt stʃɹɪŋɪŋ ɛniwʌn ʌp ənlɛs wɪv pɹuf ə ðɛɹ kɹaɪmz. wʌns ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz seɪfli bæk wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ, jə kən stɑɹt sɔɹɾɪŋ θɹu ðə sɛl-sɔɹdz ən si ɪf jə kən tʃɑɹdʒ ɛni ʌv ðɛm. əntɪl ðɛn, ðəɹ dʒʌs hʌŋɡɹi mɛn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə fɑloʊ."

"Your queen is my leigewoman," Perrin said as they reached the front of the column. "We're not stringing anyone up unless we have proof of their crimes. Once everyone is safely back where they belong, you can start sorting through the sell-swords and see if you can charge any of them. Until then, they're just hungry men looking for someone to follow."

ɑɹɡændə smɛl fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. pɛɹɪn hæd ɡeɪn ə fju wiks ʌv ɡʊdwɪl fɹəm ɪm ən ɡælɛn fɑloʊɪŋ ðə səksɛsfəl əsɔlt ɑn meɪɾən, bʌɾ oʊl dɪvɪʒənz wɝ ɹisɝfəsɪŋ ɪn ði ɛnləs mʌd, ʌndɝ ə skaɪ fʊl ə tʌmbəlɪŋ θʌndɝhɛdz.

Arganda smelled frustrated. Perrin had gained a few weeks of goodwill from him and Gallenne following the successful assault on Maiden, but old divisions were resurfacing in the endless mud, under a sky full of tumbling thunderheads.

"doʊnt wɝi jɝsɛlf," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæv mɛn wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə nukʌmɝz." hi ɔlsoʊ hæɾ əm wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz. səm wɝ soʊ dɑsəl ðət ðeɪ wəd hɑɹdli ɡoʊ tə ðə pɹɪvi wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə də soʊ; ʌðɝz kɛp lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ʃeɪɾoʊ tə spɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɪstən laɪn ʌv oʊks ən switɡəm tʃɹiz əɾ ɛni moʊmənt. pipəl u smɛl ðət tɛɹəfaɪd kəd bi tʃɹʌbəl, ən ðə vɛɹiəs fækʃənz ə hɪz kæmp ɔlɹɛɾi wɔkt əz ɪf tʃɹʌdʒɪŋ θɹu ɪtʃwid.

"Don't worry yourself," Perrin said. "I have men watching over the newcomers." He also had them watching the refugees. Some were so docile that they would hardly go to the privy without being instructed to do so; others kept looking over their shoulders, as if expecting Shaido to spring from the distant line of oaks and sweetgum trees at any moment. People who smelled that terrified could be trouble, and the various factions of his camp already walked as if trudging through itchweed.

"ju meɪ sɛn sʌmwʌn tə tɔk tə ðə nukʌmɝz, ɑɹɡændə," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "tɔk oʊnli. faɪn aʊt wɛɹ ðəɹ fɹʌm, lɝn wɛðɝ ðeɪ dɪd sɝv ə lɔɹd, si ɪf ðeɪ kən æɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə ðə mæps."

"You may send someone to talk to the newcomers, Arganda," Perrin said. "Talk only. Find out where they're from, learn whether they did serve a lord, see if they can add anything to the maps."

ðeɪ dɪdn əv ɛni ɡʊd mæps ə ði ɛɹiə, ən hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə hæv ðə ɡildænɪn mɛn -  ɑɹɡændə ɪnkluɾəd - dʒɹɔ səm fɹəm mɛmɹi.

They didn't have any good maps of the area, and had been forced to have the Ghealdanin men -  Arganda included - draw some from memory.

ɑɹɡændə ɹoʊɾ ɔf, ən pɛɹɪn muv tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɑləm. biɪŋ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ dɪɾ əv ɪts naɪs moʊməns; ʌp hɪɹ, ðə smɛlz ʌv ənwɑʃt bɑɾiz ən pʌnʒənt mʌd wɝnt nɪɹli soʊ stʃɹɔŋ. əhɛd, hi kəd faɪnəli si ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd laɪk ə lɔŋ stʃɹæp ə lɛðɝ kʌɾɪŋ θɹu ðə haɪlən pleɪnz, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ə nɔɹθwɛstɝn dɝɛkʃən.

Arganda rode off, and Perrin moved to the front of the column. Being in charge did have its nice moments; up here, the smells of unwashed bodies and pungent mud weren't nearly so strong. Ahead, he could finally see the Jehannah Road like a long strap of leather cutting through the highland plains, running in a northwestern direction.

pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd, lɔst ɪn θɔt fəɹ ə taɪm. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ðə mʌd dɪdn lʊk əz bæɾ ɑn ðə ɹoʊɾ əz ɪt hæɾ ɪn ðə mɛdoʊz -  ðoʊ ɪf ɪt wɝ laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ ɹoʊd pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɹævəld ɑn, ɪt wəɾ əv ɪts maɪɹz ən wɑʃt-aʊt sɛkʃənz. əz i ɹitʃt ɪt, hi noʊɾəst ɡɔl əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. ði il hæd bɪn ɔf skaʊɾɪŋ əhɛd, ən əz pɛɹɪnz hɔɹs stɛpt ʌp ɑntu ðə ɹoʊd, hi noʊɾəst ðət sʌmwʌn wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪnd ɡɔl ʌp təwɔɹd ðɛm.

Perrin rode, lost in thought for a time. Eventually, they reached the roadway. The mud didn't look as bad on the road as it had in the meadows -  though if it were like any other road Perrin had traveled on, it would have its mires and washed-out sections. As he reached it, he noticed Gaul approaching. The Aiel had been off scouting ahead, and as Perrin's horse stepped up onto the road, he noticed that someone was riding behind Gaul up toward them.

ɪt wɑz fɛnəl, wʌn ə ðə fɛɹiɝz ðət pɛɹɪn hæd sɛn əhɛd wɪð mæstɝ ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz.

It was Fennel, one of the farriers that Perrin had sent ahead with Master Gill and the others.

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə wɑʃ ə ɹɪlif tə si hɪm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ wɝi. wɛɹ wɝ ði ʌðɝz?

Perrin felt a wash of relief to see him, but it was followed by worry. Where were the others?

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn!" ðə mæn sɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp. ɡɔl stɛp tə ðə saɪd. fɛnəl wɑz ə waɪd-ʃoʊldɝd mæn, ən kæɹiɾ ə lɔŋ-hændəld wɝkmənz æks stʃɹæp tə hɪz bæk. hi smɛld ə ɹɪlif. "pɹeɪz ðə laɪt. aɪ θɔt jud nɛvɝ ɡɛt hɪɹ. jəɹ mæn sɛz ðə ɹɛskju wɝkt?"

"Lord Perrin!" the man said, riding up. Gaul stepped to the side. Fennel was a wide-shouldered man, and carried a long-handled workman's axe strapped to his back. He smelled of relief. "Praise the Light. I thought you'd never get here. Your man says the rescue worked?"

"ɪt dɪd, fɛnəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "wɛɹ ɑɹ ði ʌðɝz?"

"It did, Fennel," Perrin said, frowning. "Where are the others?"

"ðeɪ wɛn ɑn əhɛd, maɪ lɔɹd," fɛnəl sɛd, boʊɪŋ fɹəm hɔɹsbæk. "aɪ vɑləntɪɹd tə steɪ bɪhaɪnd, fəɹ wən jə kɑɾ ʌp. wi niɾəd tə ɪkspleɪn, jə si."

"They went on ahead, my Lord," Fennel said, bowing from horseback. "I volunteered to stay behind, for when you caught up. We needed to explain, you see."

"ɪkspleɪn?"

"Explain?"

"ðə ɹɛs tɝn təwɔɹd luɡɹd," fɛnəl ɪkspleɪnd. "əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd."

"The rest turned toward Lugard," Fennel explained. "Along the road."

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn sɛd, fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. "aɪ ɡeɪv əm ɔɹɾɝz tə kəntɪnju nɔɹθwɝd!"

"What?" Perrin said, frustrated. "I gave them orders to continue northward!"

"maɪ lɔɹd," fɛnəl sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əbæʃt. "wi mɛt tʃɹævəlɝz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət weɪ; sɛd ðət mʌd meɪd ðə ɹoʊdz tə ðə nɔɹθ ɔlmoʊs kəmplitli ɪmpæsəbəl fəɹ wæɡənz əɹ kɑɹts. mæstɝ ɡɪl dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət hɛɾɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn θɹu luɡɹd wəd bi ðə bɛst weɪ tə fɑloʊ jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz. sɑɹi, maɪ lɔɹd.

"My Lord," Fennel said, looking abashed. "We met travelers coming from that way; said that mud made the roads to the north almost completely impassable for wagons or carts. Master Gill decided that heading to Caemlyn through Lugard would be the best way to follow your orders. Sorry, my Lord.

ðæts waɪ wʌn ʌv əs hæd tə steɪ bɪhaɪnd."

That's why one of us had to stay behind."

laɪt! noʊ wʌndɝ ðə skaʊts hædn faʊnd ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪd ɡɔn ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ dɝɛkʃən.

Light! No wonder the scouts hadn't found Gill and the others. They'd gone in the wrong direction.

wɛl, æftɝ slɑɡɪŋ θɹu mʌd fəɹ wiks hɪmsɛlf - səmtaɪmz hævɪŋ tə stɑp ən weɪɾ aʊt stɔɹmz -  pɛɹɪn kʊdn bleɪm əm fəɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə teɪk ðə ɹoʊd. ðət dɪdn stɑp ɪm fɹəm filɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd.

Well, after slogging through mud for weeks himself - sometimes having to stop and wait out storms -  Perrin couldn't blame them for deciding to take the road. That didn't stop him from feeling frustrated.

"haʊ fɑɹ bɪhaɪn ɑɹ wi?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"How far behind are we?" Perrin asked.

"aɪv bɪn hɪɹ faɪv deɪz, maɪ lɔɹd."

"I've been here five days, my Lord."

soʊ ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn sloʊd tu. wɛl, ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ, ət list.

So Gill and the others had been slowed too. Well, that was something, at least.

"ɡoʊ ɡɛt jɝsɛlf sʌmθɪŋ tə it, fɛnəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn θæŋk jə fəɹ steɪɪŋ bɪhaɪn tə lemi noʊ wʌt hæpənd. ɪt wɑz ə bɹeɪv θɪŋ jə dɪd, weɪɾɪŋ əloʊn fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ."

"Go get yourself something to eat, Fennel," Perrin said. "And thank you for staying behind to let me know what happened. It was a brave thing you did, waiting alone for so long."

"sʌmbɑɾi hæd tə də ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "moʊs fɪɹd jə hædnt . . . wɛl, ðət θɪŋz hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ, maɪ lɔɹd. jə si, wi fɪɡjɝd jud bi fæstɝ ðən ʌs, sɪns wi hæd ðoʊz kɑɹts. bʌt fɹəm ðə lʊk ə θɪŋz hɪɹ, jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɹɪŋ ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊn wɪð ju!"

"Somebody had to do it, my Lord." He hesitated. "Most feared you hadn't . . . well, that things had gone wrong, my Lord. You see, we figured you'd be faster than us, since we had those carts. But from the look of things here, you decided to bring the entire town with you!"

ɪt wɑzn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə tʃɹuθ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. hi weɪv fɛnəl ɑn.

It wasn't far from the truth, unfortunately. He waved Fennel on.

"aɪ faʊn ɪm əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd," ɡɔl sɛd sɔfli. "bɪsaɪɾ ə hɪl ðət wəd meɪk ən ɛksələn kæmp. wɛl wɔɾɝd, wɪð ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ ɛɹiə."

"I found him about an hour along the road," Gaul said softly. "Beside a hill that would make an excellent camp. Well watered, with a good view of the surrounding area."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. ðeɪɾ əv tə dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də - weɪɾ əntɪl ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil kəd meɪk lɑɹdʒ ɡeɪtweɪz, fɑloʊ əlɔŋ æftɝ mæstɝ ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɑn fʊt, əɹ sɛn moʊs pipəl nɔɹθwɝɾ ən sɛn oʊnli ə fju təwɔɹd luɡɹd. ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə dɪsɪʒən, ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə kæmp fəɹ ðə deɪ ən sɔɹt θɹu θɪŋz.

Perrin nodded. They'd have to decide what to do - wait until Grady and Neald could make large gateways, follow along after Master Gill and the others on foot, or send most people northward and send only a few toward Lugard. Regardless of the decision, it would be good to camp for the day and sort through things.

"pæs ðə wɝd tə ði ʌðɝz, ɪf jə wɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə ɡɔl. "wil haɪk daʊn ðə ɹoʊd tə ðə pleɪs jə faʊnd, ðən dɪskʌs wʌt tə də nɛkst. ən æsk səm ə ðə meɪɾənz ɪf ðeɪd skaʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən tə meɪk ʃʊɹ wɝ nɑt gɑnə bi sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ɛniwʌn muvɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn ʌs."

"Pass the word to the others, if you will," Perrin said to Gaul. "We'll hike down the road to the place you found, then discuss what to do next. And ask some of the Maidens if they'd scout along the road in the other direction to make sure we're not going to be surprised by anyone moving up the road behind us."

ɡɔl nɑɾəd ən muvd ɔf tə pæs ðə wɝd. pɛɹɪn ɹɪmeɪn sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp steɪɝ, θɪŋkɪŋ. hi hæd hæf ə maɪn tə sɛn ɑɹɡændə ən ɔiɑndɝ ɔf tə ðə nɔɹθwɛst ɹaɪt naʊ, sɛɾɪŋ ɑn ə pæθ tə dʒəhænə. bʌt ðə meɪɾənz hæd pɪkt aʊt səm ʃeɪɾoʊ skaʊts wɑtʃɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmi. ðoʊz wɝ pɹɑbli ðəɹ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ pɛɹɪn wɑzn ə θɹɛt, bʌt ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪm ənizi. ðiz wɝ deɪnʒɝəs taɪmz.

Gaul nodded and moved off to pass the word. Perrin remained sitting atop Stayer, thinking. He had half a mind to send Arganda and AUiandre off to the northwest right now, setting on a path to Jehannah. But the Maidens had picked out some Shaido scouts watching his army. Those were probably there to make sure Perrin wasn't a threat, but they made him uneasy. These were dangerous times.

ɪt wɑz bɛs tə kip ɔiɑndɝ ən əɹ pipəl wɪð ɪm fəɹ naʊ, boʊθ fəɹ əɹ seɪfti ən ɪz oʊn, ət list əntɪl ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild ɹəkʌvɝd. ðə sneɪkbaɪts fɹəm ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl hæɾ əfɛktəd ðə tu ʌv əm ən mɑsʊɝi - ði oʊnli wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd bɪn bɪɾən - wɝs ðən ði ʌðɝz.

It was best to keep AUiandre and her people with him for now, both for her safety and his own, at least until Grady and Neald recovered. The snakebites from the bubble of evil had affected the two of them and Masuri - the only one of the Aes Sedai who had been bitten - worse than the others.

stɪl, ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə lʊk heɪl əɡɛn. sun hid bi eɪbəl tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə muv ði ɑɹmi θɹu. ðən pɛɹɪn kəd sɛn ɔiɑndɝ ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn hoʊm. hi hɪmsɛlf kəd tʃɹævəl bæk tə ɹænd, pɹitɛn tə meɪk ʌp - moʊs pipəl wəd stɪl θɪŋk ðəɾ i ən ɹænd hæd pɑɹɾəd weɪz æŋɡɹəli - ən ðən faɪnəli bi ɹɪɾ ə bɹəleɪn ən əɹ wɪŋd ɡɑɹd. ɛvɹiθɪŋ kəd ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə weɪ ɪt ʃəd bi.

Still, Grady was starting to look hale again. Soon he'd be able to make a gateway large enough to move the army through. Then Perrin could send AUiandre and the Two Rivers men home. He himself could Travel back to Rand, pretend to make up - most people would still think that he and Rand had parted ways angrily - and then finally be rid of Berelain and her Winged Guard. Everything could go back to the way it should be.

laɪt sɛn ɪɾ ɔl wɛn ðəɾ izəli. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, dɪspɛlɪŋ ðə swɝlɪŋ kʌlɝz ən vɪʒənz ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə hɪz aɪz wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ ə ɹænd.

Light send it all went that easily. He shook his head, dispelling the swirling colors and visions that appeared to his eyes whenever he thought of Rand.

nɪɹbaɪ, bɹəleɪn ən əɹ fɔɹs wɝ mɑɹtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹoʊd, lʊkɪŋ vɛɹi pliz tə ɹitʃ səm sɑləd fʊɾɪŋ. ðə bjuɾəfəl dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən wɔɹ ə faɪn ɡɹin dʒɹɛs ən ə bɛlt ə faɪɝdʒɹɑps.

Nearby, Berelain and her force were marching out onto the road, looking very pleased to reach some solid footing. The beautiful dark-haired woman wore a fine green dress and a belt of firedrops.

hɝ nɛklaɪn wɑz dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋli loʊ. hid stɑɹɾəd ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn əɹ dʊɹɪŋ feɪlz æbsəns, wʌns ʃid stɑp tʃɹiɾɪŋ ɪm laɪk ə pɹaɪz bɔɹ tə bi hʌntəɾ ən skɪnd.

Her neckline was discomfortingly low. He'd started relying on her during Faile's absence, once she'd stopped treating him like a prize boar to be hunted and skinned.

feɪl wɑz bæk naʊ, ən ɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪz tʃɹus wɪð bɹəleɪn wɑz oʊvɝ. əz juʒəwəl, ənʊɹə ɹoʊd nɪɹ hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi dɪdn spɛn ðə taɪm tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð bɹəleɪn əz ʃi wʌns hæd. pɛɹɪn nɛvɝ hæd fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt waɪ ʃid bɪn miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə pɹɑfət. pɹɑbli nɛvɝ wʊd, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wʌt hæd hæpən tə mæsimə. ə deɪ aʊɾ ə meɪɾən, pɛɹɪnz skaʊts hæd ɹʌn əkɹɔs ə ɡɹup ə kɔɹpsəz ðət hæd bɪn kɪld wɪð æɹoʊz ən ɹɑbd ə ðɛɹ ʃuz, bɛls, ən ɛni væljəbəlz. ðoʊ ɹeɪvənz hæd ɡɑɾən ði aɪz, pɛɹɪn hæd smɛl mæsiməz sɛn θɹu ðə ɹɑt.

Faile was back now, and it appeared his truce with Berelain was over. As usual, Annoura rode near her, though she didn't spend the time chatting with Berelain as she once had. Perrin never had figured out why she'd been meeting with the Prophet. Probably never would, considering what had happened to Masema. A day out of Maiden, Perrin's scouts had run across a group of corpses that had been killed with arrows and robbed of their shoes, belts, and any valuables. Though ravens had gotten the eyes, Perrin had smelled Masema's scent through the rot.

ðə pɹɑfət wɑz dɛd, kɪl baɪ bændəts. wɛl, pɝhæps ðət wɑz ə fɪɾɪŋ ɛn fəɹ hɪm, bʌt pɛɹɪn stɪl fɛl hid feɪld. ɹænd hæd wɑntəd mæsimə bɹɔt tə hɪm. ðə kʌlɝz swɝld əɡɛn. iðɝ weɪ, ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə ɹɪtɝn tə ɹænd. ðə kʌlɝz swɝld, ʃoʊɪŋ ɹænd stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ wɪð ə bɝn fɹʌnt, stɛɹɪŋ wɛstwɝd. pɛɹɪn bænɪʃt ði ɪmədʒ. hɪz duɾi wɑz dʌn, ðə pɹɑfət sin tə, æliændɝz əlidʒəns sɪkjʊɹ. oʊnli, pɛɹɪn fɛlt əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ wɝ stɪl vɛɹi ɹɔŋ.

The Prophet was dead, killed by bandits. Well, perhaps that was a fitting end for him, but Perrin still felt he'd failed. Rand had wanted Masema brought to him. The colors swirled again. Either way, it was time for Perrin to return to Rand. The colors swirled, showing Rand standing in front of a building with a burned front, staring westward. Perrin banished the image. His duty was done, the Prophet seen to, Alliandre's allegiance secure. Only, Perrin felt as if something were still very wrong.

hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl ɪn ɪz pɑkət. tə ʌndɝstæn sʌmθɪŋ. . . juv tə fɪɡjɝ aʊɾ ɪts pɑɹts . . .

He fingered the blacksmith's puzzle in his pocket. To understand something. . . you have to figure out its parts . . .

hi smɛl feɪl bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt hɪm, hɝɾ əɹ hɔɹs ɑn ðə sɑft ɝθ. "soʊ, ɡɪl tɝn təwɔɹd luɡɹd?" ʃi æskt, stɑpɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm.

He smelled Faile before she reached him, heard her horse on the soft earth. "So, Gill turned toward Lugard?" she asked, stopping beside him.

hi nɑɾəd.

He nodded.

"ðæt meɪ hæv bɪn waɪz. pɝhæps wi ʃəd tɝn ðət weɪ tu. wɝ ðoʊz mɔɹ sɛl-sɔɹdz u dʒɔɪn ʌs?"

"That may have been wise. Perhaps we should turn that way too. Were those more sell-swords who joined us?"

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"wi mʌst əv pɪkt ʌp faɪv θaʊzən pipəl ðiz læs fju wiks," ʃi sɛd θɔtfəli.

"We must have picked up five thousand people these last few weeks," she said thoughtfully.

"pɝhæps mɔɹ. ɑd, ɪn ðɪs dɛsələt lændskeɪp."

"Perhaps more. Odd, in this desolate landscape."

ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl, wɪð əɹ ɹeɪvən hɛɹ ən stʃɹɔŋ fitʃɝz - ə ɡʊd sɑldəiən noʊz sɛt bɪtwin tu tɪltəɾ aɪz. ʃi wɑz dʒɹɛs fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn dip waɪn ɹɛd. hi lʌvd əɹ dɪɹli, ən pɹeɪz ðə laɪt ðət hid ɡɑɾən əɹ bæk. waɪ dɪɾ i fil soʊ ɑkwɝɾ ɝaʊn əɹ naʊ?

She was beautiful, with her raven hair and strong features - a good Saldaean nose set between two tilted eyes. She was dressed for riding in deep wine red. He loved her dearly, and praised the Light that he'd gotten her back. Why did he feel so awkward around her now?

"jɔɹ tʃɹʌbəld, maɪ hʌzbənd," ʃi noʊɾəd. ʃi ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪm soʊ wɛl, ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ʃi kəd ɹid sɛns. ɪt sim tə bi ə θɪŋ ʌv wɪmən, ðoʊ. bɹəleɪn kəd də ɪt tu.

"You're troubled, my husband," she noted. She understood him so well, it was almost as if she could read scents. It seemed to be a thing of women, though. Berelain could do it too.

"wiv ɡæðɝd tu mɛni pipəl," hi sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt. "aɪ ʃəd stɑɹt tɝnɪŋ əm əweɪ."

"We've gathered too many people," he said with a grunt. "I should start turning them away."

"aɪ səspɛk ðeɪd faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ bæk tə əɹ fɔɹs ɛniweɪ."

"I suspect they'd find their way back to our force anyway."

"waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ? aɪ kəd liv ɔɹɾɝz."

"Why should they? I could leave orders."

"ju kænt ɡɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf, maɪ hʌzbənd." ʃi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ət ðə kɑləm ə pipəl əz ðeɪ muvd ɑntu ðə ɹoʊd.

"You can't give orders to the Pattern itself, my husband." She glanced over at the column of people as they moved onto the road.

"wʌt də - " hi kʌɾ ɔf, kætʃɪŋ əɹ minɪŋ. "ju θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz mi? biɪŋ tɑvɝən?'

"What do - " He cut off, catching her meaning. "You think this is me? Being ta'veren?'

"ɛvɹi stɑp əlɔŋ əɹ tʃɹɪp, juv ɡeɪn mɔɹ fɑloʊɝz," feɪl sɛd. "dɪspaɪɾ əɹ lɔsəz əɡɛns ði il, wi keɪm aʊɾ ə meɪɾən wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋɝ fɔɹs ðən wən wi stɑɹɾəd. hævən jə faʊn ɪɾ ɑd ðət soʊ mɛni ʌv ðə fɔɹmɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ tə tɑɹnz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɪð wɛpənz?"

"Every stop along our trip, you've gained more followers," Faile said. "Despite our losses against the Aiel, we came out of Maiden with a stronger force than when we started. Haven't you found it odd that so many of the former gai'shain are taking to Tarn's training with weapons?"

"ðeɪ wɝ biɾən daʊn soʊ lɔŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ wɑnə stɑp ðət fɹəm hæpənɪŋ əɡɛn."

"They were beaten down so long," Perrin said. "They want to stop that from happening again."

"æn soʊ kupɝz lɝn ðə sɔɹd," feɪl sɛd, "æn faɪn ðeɪv ə tælən fəɹ ɪt. meɪsənz u nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə faɪɾɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ naʊ tʃɹeɪn wɪð ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf. sɛl-sɔɹdz ən ɑɹmmɪn flɑk tə ʌs."

"And so coopers learn the sword," Faile said, "and find they have a talent for it. Masons who never thought of fighting back against the Shaido now train with the quarterstaff. Sell-swords and armsmen flock to us."

"ɪts koʊɪnsɪɾəns."

"It's coincidence."

"koʊɪnsɪɾəns?" ʃi saʊndəɾ əmjuzd. "wɪð ə tɑvɝən ət ði ɑɹmiz hɛd?"

"Coincidence?" She sounded amused. "With a ta'veren at the army's head?"

ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt, ən əz i fɛl saɪlənt, hi kəd smɛl əɹ sæɾəsfækʃən ət wɪnɪŋ ði ɑɹɡjəmənt. hi dɪdn θɪŋk ʌv ɪɾ əz ən ɑɹɡjəmənt, bʌt ʃid si ɪɾ əz wʌn. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ʃid bi mæd ðəɾ i hædn ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs.

She was right, and as he fell silent, he could smell her satisfaction at winning the argument. He didn't think of it as an argument, but she'd see it as one. If anything, she'd be mad that he hadn't raised his voice.

"ðɪs ɪz ɔl gɑnə ɛn ɪn ə fju deɪz, feɪl," hi sɛd. "wʌns wɪv ɡeɪtweɪz əɡɛn, əl sɛn ðiz pipəl tə ðɛɹ pɹɑpɝ pleɪsəz. aɪm nɑt ɡæðɝɪŋ ən ɑɹmi. aɪm hɛlpɪŋ səm ɹɛfjudʒiz tə ɡɛt hoʊm."

"This is all going to end in a few days, Faile," he said. "Once we have gateways again, I'll send these people to their proper places. I'm not gathering an army. I'm helping some refugees to get home."

ðə læs θɪŋ i niɾəd wɑz mɔɹ pipəl kɔlɪŋ ɪm "maɪ lɔɹd" ən boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ.

The last thing he needed was more people calling him "my Lord" and bowing and scraping.

"wi ʃæl si," ʃi sɛd.

"We shall see," she said.

"feɪl." hi saɪɾ ən loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "ə mænz ɡɑt tə si ə θɪŋ fəɹ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz. noʊ sɛns ɪn kɔlɪŋ ə bʌkəl ə hɪnʒ əɹ kɔlɪŋ ə neɪl ə hɔɹsʃu. aɪv toʊl ju; aɪm nɑɾ ə ɡʊd liɾɝ. aɪ pɹuv ðæt."

"Faile." He sighed and lowered his voice. "A man's got to see a thing for what it is. No sense in calling a buckle a hinge or calling a nail a horseshoe. I've told you; I'm not a good leader. I proved that."

"ðæts nɑt haʊ aɪ si ɪt."

"That's not how I see it."

hi ɡɹɪp ðə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl ɪn ɪz pɑkət. ðeɪd dɪskʌs ðɪs dʊɹɪŋ ðə wiks sɪns meɪɾən, bʌt ʃi ɹəfjuz tə si sɛns. "ðə kæmp wɑz ə mɛs waɪl jə wɝ ɡɔn, feɪl! aɪv toʊl jə haʊ ɑɹɡændə ən ðə meɪɾənz nɪɹli kɪld wʌn ənʌðɝ. ən ɛɹæm - mæsimə kɝʌptɪɾ ɪm ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ maɪ noʊz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pleɪɾ ət ɡeɪmz aɪ kænt ɡɛs, ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn . . . jə si haʊ ðeɪ lʊk ət mi wɪð ʃeɪm ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz."

He gripped the blacksmith's puzzle in his pocket. They'd discussed this during the weeks since Maiden, but she refused to see sense. "The camp was a mess while you were gone, Faile! I've told you how Arganda and the Maidens nearly killed one another. And Aram - Masema corrupted him right under my nose. The Aes Sedai played at games I can't guess, and the Two Rivers men . . . you see how they look at me with shame in their eyes."

feɪlz sɛn spaɪkt wɪð æŋɡɝ wən i sɛd ðæt, ən ʃi tɝnd ʃɑɹpli təwɔɹd bɹəleɪn.

Faile's scent spiked with anger when he said that, and she turned sharply toward Berelain.

"ɪts nɑɾ əɹ fɔlt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪf aɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, aɪɾ əv stɑp ðə ɹumɝz dɛd.

"It's not her fault," Perrin said. "If I'd been able to think of it, I'd have stopped the rumors dead.

bʌɾ aɪ dɪdnt. naʊ aɪv ɡɑt tə slip ɪn ðə bɛɾ aɪ meɪd fəɹ maɪsɛlf. laɪt! wʌɾ ɪz ə mæn ɪf ɪz oʊn neɪbɝz doʊn θɪŋk wɛl ə hɪm? ɪm noʊ lɔɹd, feɪl, ən ðæts ðæt. aɪv pɹuvən ɪt saʊnli."

But I didn't. Now I've got to sleep in the bed I made for myself. Light! What is a man if his own neighbors don't think well of him? I'm no lord, Faile, and that's that. I've proven it soundly."

"ɑd," ʃi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪv bɪn spikɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝz, ən ðeɪ tɛl ə dɪfɹən stɔɹi. ðeɪ seɪ ðət jə kɛpt ɑɹɡændə kənteɪn ən pʊɾ aʊt flɛɹ-ʌps ɪn kæmp. ðən ðɛɹz ði əlaɪəns wɪð ðə sintʃæn; ðə mɔɹ aɪ lɝn ə ðæt, ðə mɔɹ ɪmpɹɛst aɪ æm. jə æktəd dɪsaɪsɪvli ɪn ə taɪm ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ənsɝɾənti, jə foʊkəst ɛvɹiwʌnz ɛfɝts, ən jə əkɑmplɪʃt ði ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪn teɪkɪŋ meɪɾən.

"Odd," she said. "But I've been speaking to the others, and they tell a different story. They say that you kept Arganda contained and put out flare-ups in camp. Then there's the alliance with the Seanchan; the more I learn of that, the more impressed I am. You acted decisively in a time of great uncertainty, you focused everyone's efforts, and you accomplished the impossible in taking Maiden.

ðoʊz ɑɹ ði ækʃənz ʌv ə liɾɝ."

Those are the actions of a leader."

"feɪl . . ." hi sɛd, səpɹɛsɪŋ ə ɡɹaʊl. waɪ wʊdnt ʃi lɪsən? wən ʃid bɪn ə kæptɪv, nʌθɪŋ hæd mæɾɝd tə hɪm bʌt ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ hɝ. nɑθ-ɪŋ. ɪt dɪdn mæɾɝ u hæd niɾəd ɪz hɛlp, əɹ wʌɾ ɔɹɾɝz hid bɪn ɡɪvən. tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪtsɛlf kəɾ əv stɑɹɾəd, ən hiɾ əv ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə faɪn feɪl.

"Faile . . ." he said, suppressing a growl. Why wouldn't she listen? When she'd been a captive, nothing had mattered to him but recovering her. Noth-ing. It didn't matter who had needed his help, or what orders he'd been given. Tarmon Gai'don itself could have started, and he'd have ignored it in order to find Faile.

hi ɹiliɾuɛd naʊ haʊ deɪnʒɝəs ɪz ækʃənz hæd bɪn. tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, hid teɪk ðoʊz seɪm ækʃənz əɡɛn. hi dɪdn ɹəɡɹɛt wʌt hid dʌn, nɑt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ə liɾɝ kʊdn bi laɪk ðæt.

He reali2ed now how dangerous his actions had been. Trouble was, he'd take those same actions again. He didn't regret what he'd done, not for a moment. A leader couldn't be like that.

hi nɛvɝ ʃʊɾə lɛɾ əm ɹeɪz ðət wʊlfhɛd bænɝ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. naʊ ðət hid kəmpliɾəd ɪz tæsks, naʊ ðət feɪl wɑz bæk, ɪt wɑz taɪm tə pʊɾ ɔl ə ðət fulɪʃnəs bɪhaɪn hɪm.

He never should have let them raise that wolfhead banner in the first place. Now that he'd completed his tasks, now that Faile was back, it was time to put all of that foolishness behind him.

pɛɹɪn wɑz ə blæksmɪθ. ɪt dɪdn mæɾɝ wʌt feɪl dʒɹɛst ɪm ɪn, əɹ wʌt taɪɾəlz pipəl ɡeɪv hɪm.

Perrin was a blacksmith. It didn't matter what Faile dressed him in, or what titles people gave him.

jə kʊdn meɪk ə dʒɹɔnaɪf ɪndə ə hɔɹsʃu baɪ peɪntɪŋ ɪt, əɹ baɪ kɔlɪŋ ɪt sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɹənt.

You couldn't make a drawknife into a horseshoe by painting it, or by calling it something different.

hi tɝn tə ðə saɪd, wɛɹ dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ ɹoʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə kɑləm, ðət blæstəd ɹɛd wʊlfhɛd bænɝ flæpɪŋ pɹaʊdli fɹəm ə poʊl tɔlɝ ðən ə kævəlɹimənz læns. pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə ʃaʊt fəɹ ɪm tə teɪk ɪt daʊn, bʌt feɪl spoʊk sʌɾənli.

He turned to the side, where Jori Congar rode before the column, that blasted red wolfhead banner flapping proudly from a pole taller than a cavalryman's lance. Perrin opened his mouth to shout for him to take it down, but Faile spoke suddenly.

"jɛs, ɪndid," ʃi sɛd, mjuzɪŋli. "aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ðɪs fəɹ ðə læs fju wiks, ən - ɑd ðoʊ ɪt simz - aɪ bɪliv maɪ kæptɪvəɾi meɪ hæv bɪn pɹɪsaɪsli wʌt wi niɾəd. boʊθ ʌv ʌs."

"Yes, indeed," she said, musingly. "I've been thinking on this for the last few weeks, and - odd though it seems - I believe my captivity may have been precisely what we needed. Both of us."

wʌt? pɛɹɪn tɝn tə hɝ, smɛlɪŋ əɹ θɔtfəlnəs. ʃi bɪlivd wʌt ʃid sɛd.

What? Perrin turned to her, smelling her thoughtfulness. She believed what she'd said.

"naʊ," feɪl sɛd, "wi nid tə spik ʌv - "

"Now," Faile said, "we need to speak of - "

"skaʊts ɹɪtɝnɪŋ," hi sɛd, pɝhæps mɔɹ əbɹʌpli ðən i ɪntɛndəd. "il ʌp əhɛd."

"Scouts returning," he said, perhaps more abruptly than he intended. "Aiel up ahead."

feɪl ɡlænst əz i pɔɪntəd, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs ʃi kʊdn si ɛniθɪŋ jɛt. ʃi nu ʌv ɪz aɪz, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu dɪd.

Faile glanced as he pointed, but of course she couldn't see anything yet. She knew of his eyes, though. She was one of the few who did.

ðə kɔl wɛn ʌp əz ʌðɝz noʊɾəst ðə θɹi fɪɡjɝz ɪn keɪɾɪnsɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd, ðə wʌnz pɛɹɪn hæd sɛn tə skaʊt. tu meɪɾənz hɝid fəɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz ən wʌn loʊpt ʌp tə pɛɹɪn.

The call went up as others noticed the three figures in cadin'sor approaching alongside the road, the ones Perrin had sent to scout. Two Maidens hurried for the Wise Ones and one loped up to Perrin.

"ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ðə wʊmən sɛd. ʃi smɛl kənsɝnd.

"There is something beside the road, Perrin Aybara," the woman said. She smelled concerned.

ðət wɑz ə deɪnʒɝəs saɪn. "ɪɾ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ðət jəl wɪʃ tə si."

That was a dangerous sign. "It is something that you will wish to see."
