ɡɑləd woʊk tə ðə saʊn ʌv ə tɛn flæp ɹʌslɪŋ. ʃɑɹp peɪnz bɝn əɾ ɪz saɪd wɛɹ i hæd bɪn ɹɪpiɾɪdli kɪkt; ðeɪ mætʃt ðə dʌlɝ eɪks ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, lɛft ɑɹm, ən θaɪ wɛɹ hid bɪn wundəd baɪ vɑldə. hɪz paʊndɪŋ hɛdeɪk wɑz ɔlmoʊst stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaʊn aʊɾ ɔl ɛls.

Galad woke to the sound of a tent flap rustling. Sharp pains burned at his side where he had been repeatedly kicked; they matched the duller aches on his shoulder, left arm, and thigh where he'd been wounded by Valda. His pounding headache was almost strong enough to drown out all else.

hi ɡɹoʊnd, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑntu hɪz bæk. ɔl wɑz dɑɹk ɝaʊn hɪm, bʌt pɪnpɹɪk laɪts ʃoʊn ɪn ðə skaɪ.

He groaned, rolling onto his back. All was dark around him, but pinprick lights shone in the sky.

stɑɹz? ɪt hæd bɪn oʊvɝkæs fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ.

Stars? It had been overcast for so long.

noʊ . . . sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. hɪz hɛd pʌlsd wɪð peɪn, ən i blɪŋk tɪɹz fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪz. ðoʊz stɑɹz lʊk soʊ feɪnt, soʊ dɪstənt. ðeɪ meɪd noʊ fəmɪljɝ pæɾɝnz. wɛɹ kəɾ əsunɑwə hæv teɪkən ɪm ðət ðə vɛɹi stɑɹz wɝ dɪfɹənt?

No . . . something was wrong about them. His head pulsed with pain, and he blinked tears from the corner of his eyes. Those stars looked so faint, so distant. They made no familiar patterns. Where could Asunawa have taken him that the very stars were different?

əz ɪz maɪn klɪɹd, hi bɪɡæn tə meɪk aʊɾ ɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz. ðɪs wɑz ə hɛvi slipɪŋ tɛnt, kənstʃɹʌktəd tə bi dɑɹk dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪlaɪɾ aʊɝz. ðə laɪts əbʌv wɝn stɑɹz əɾ ɔl, bʌt sʌnlaɪt θɹu ði əkeɪʒənəl pɪnhoʊlz ʌv wɛɹ ɪn ðə kænvəs.

As his mind cleared, he began to make out his surroundings. This was a heavy sleeping tent, constructed to be dark during the daylight hours. The lights above weren't stars at all, but sunlight through the occasional pinholes of wear in the canvas.

hi wɑz stɪl neɪkəd, ən wɪð tɛntəɾɪv fɪŋɡɝz i dɪtɝmən ðət ðəɹ wɑz dʒɹaɪd blʌɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. ɪt hæd kʌm fɹəm ə lɔŋ ɡæʃ ɪn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ɪf i dɪdnt wɑʃ ɪt sun, ɪnfɛkʃən wɑz laɪkli. hi leɪ ɑn ɪz bæk, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt wɪð kɛɹ. ɪf i tʊk ɪn tu mʌtʃ ɛɹ ət wʌns, hɪz saɪd skɹimd.

He was still naked, and with tentative fingers he determined that there was dried blood on his face. It had come from a long gash in his forehead. If he didn't wash it soon, infection was likely. He lay on his back, breathing in and out with care. If he took in too much air at once, his side screamed.

ɡɑləd dɪd nɑt fɪɹ dɛθ əɹ peɪn. hi hæd meɪd ðə ɹaɪt tʃɔɪsəz. ɪt wɑz ənfɔɹtʃənət ðət hid niɾəd tə liv ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ; ðeɪ wɝ kəntʃɹoʊl baɪ ðə sintʃæn. haʊɛvɝ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ʌðɝ ɑpʃən, nɑɾ æftɝ hid wɔkt ɪndə əsunɑwəz hænz.

Galad did not fear death or pain. He had made the right choices. It was unfortunate that he'd needed to leave the Questioners in charge; they were controlled by the Seanchan. However, there had been no other option, not after he'd walked into Asunawa's hands.

ɡɑləd fɛl noʊ æŋɡɝ ət ðə skaʊts u hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd hɪm. ðə kwɛstʃənɝz wɝ ə væləd sɔɹs ʌv əθɔɹəɾi ɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ən ðɛɹ laɪz hæd noʊ daʊt bɪn kənvɪnsɪŋ. noʊ, ðə wʌn i wɑz æŋɡɹi ət wɑz əsunɑwə, hu tʊk wʌt wɑz tʃɹu ən mʌɾid ɪt. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni hu dɪd ðəɾ ɪn ðə wɝld, bʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ʃəd bi dɪfɹənt.

Galad felt no anger at the scouts who had betrayed him. The Questioners were a valid source of authority in the Children, and their lies had no doubt been convincing. No, the one he was angry at was Asunawa, who took what was true and muddied it. There were many who did that in the world, but the Children should be different.

sun ðə kwɛstʃənɝz wəd kʌm fəɹ hɪm, ən ðən ðə tʃɹu pɹaɪs fəɹ seɪvɪŋ ɪz mɛn wəd bi ɪɡzæktɪd wɪð ðɛɹ hʊks ən naɪvz. hi hæd bɪn əwɛɹ ə ðət pɹaɪs wən hid meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən. ɪn ə weɪ, hi hæd wʌn, fəɹ i hæd mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən bɛst.

Soon the Questioners would come for him, and then the true price for saving his men would be exacted with their hooks and knives. He had been aware of that price when he'd made his decision. In a way, he had won, for he had manipulated the situation best.

ði ʌðɝ weɪ tə ɛnʃʊɹ ɪz vɪktɝi wɑz tə hoʊl tə ðə tʃɹuθ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ. tə dɪnaɪ biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wɪð ɪz faɪnəl bɹɛθ. ɪt wəd bi dɪfəkəlt, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi ɹaɪt.

The other way to ensure his victory was to hold to the truth under their questioning. To deny being a Darkfriend with his final breath. It would be difficult, but it would be right.

hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə sɪɾ ʌp, ɪkspɛktɪŋ - ən wɛðɝɪŋ - ðə dɪzinəs ən nɔziə. hi fɛlt ɝaʊnd. hɪz lɛɡz wɝ tʃeɪn təɡɛðɝ, ən ðət tʃeɪn wɑz lɑk tə ə spaɪk ðət hæd bɪn dʒɹɪvən dip ɪndə ði ɝθ, pɪɹsɪŋ ðə ɹʌf kænvəs tɛn bɑɾəm.

He forced himself to sit up, expecting - and weathering - the dizziness and nausea. He felt around. His legs were chained together, and that chain was locked to a spike that had been driven deep into the earth, piercing the rough canvas tent bottom.

hi tʃɹaɪd jæŋkɪŋ ɪt fɹi, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. hi pʊl soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz mʌsəlz feɪld ɪm ən i nɪɹli pæst aʊt. wʌns i hæd ɹəkʌvɝd, hi kɹɔl tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt. hɪz tʃeɪnz ɡeɪv ɪm ɪnʌf ɹum tə ɹitʃ ðə flæps. hi tʊk wʌn ə ðə klɔθ taɪz - juz tə hoʊl ðə flæps ʌp wən ðeɪ wɝ oʊpənd - ən spæɾ ɑn ɪt. ðɛn, məθɑɾɪkəli, hi waɪp ðə ɡɹaɪm ən blʌd fɹəm ɪz feɪs.

He tried yanking it free, just in case. He pulled so hard that his muscles failed him and he nearly passed out. Once he had recovered, he crawled to the side of the tent. His chains gave him enough room to reach the flaps. He took one of the cloth ties - used to hold the flaps up when they were opened - and spat on it. Then, methodically, he wiped the grime and blood from his face.

ðə klinɪŋ ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɡoʊl, kɛpt ɪm muvɪŋ ən stɑpt ɪm fɹəm θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə peɪn. hi kɛɹfəli skɹʌb ðə kɹʌstɪd blʌd fɹəm ɪz tʃik ən noʊz. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəlt; hɪz maʊθ wɑz dʒɹaɪ. hi bɪt daʊn ɑn ɪz tʌŋ tə ɡɛt səlaɪvə. ðə stʃɹɪps wɝ nɑt kænvəs, bʌɾ ə laɪɾɝ mətɪɹiəl. ðeɪ smɛld ə dʌst.

The cleaning gave him a goal, kept him moving and stopped him from thinking about the pain. He carefully scrubbed the crusted blood from his cheek and nose. It was difficult; his mouth was dry. He bit down on his tongue to get saliva. The strips were not canvas, but a lighter material. They smelled of dust.

hi spæɾ ɑn ə fɹɛʃ sɛkʃən, ðən wɝk ðə spɪɾəl ɪndə ðə klɔθ. ðə waʊn tə hɪz hɛd, ðə dɝɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs . . . ðiz θɪŋz wɝ mɑɹks ə vɪktɝi fəɹ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz. hi wəd nɑt liv ðɛm. hi wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ðɛɹ tɔɹtʃɝz wɪð ə klin feɪs.

He spat on a fresh section, then worked the spittle into the cloth. The wound to his head, the dirt on his face . . . these things were marks of victory for the Questioners. He would not leave them. He would go into their tortures with a clean face.

hi hɝd ʃaʊts aʊtsaɪd. mɛn pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə bɹeɪk daʊn ðə kæmp. wəd ðət dɪleɪ ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ? hi daʊɾɪd ɪt. stʃɹaɪkɪŋ kæmp kəd teɪk aʊɝz. ɡɑləd kəntɪnjud klinɪŋ, sɔɪlɪŋ ðə lɛŋθs ə boʊθ stʃɹæps, juzɪŋ ðə wɝk əz ə kaɪndə ɹɪtʃuəl, ə ɹɪðmɪk pæɾɝn tə ɡɪv ɪm ə foʊkəs fəɹ mɛɾəteɪʃən. hɪz hɛdeɪk wɪθdʒɹu, ðə peɪnz ə hɪz bɑɾi bɪkʌmɪŋ lɛs səɡnɪfɪkənt.

He heard shouts outside. Men preparing to break down the camp. Would that delay their questioning? He doubted it. Striking camp could take hours. Galad continued cleaning, soiling the lengths of both straps, using the work as a kind of ritual, a rhythmic pattern to give him a focus for meditation. His headache withdrew, the pains of his body becoming less significant.

hi wəd nɑt ɹʌn. ivən ɪf i kəɾ ɪskeɪp, fliɪŋ wəɾ ɪnvælɪdeɪɾ ɪz bɑɹɡən wɪð əsunɑwə.

He would not run. Even if he could escape, fleeing would invalidate his bargain with Asunawa.

bʌɾ i wəd feɪs ɪz ɛnəmiz wɪð sɛlf-ɹɪspɛkt.

But he would face his enemies with self-respect.

əz i fɪnɪʃt, hi hɝd vɔɪsəz aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛnt. ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. hi skɹæbəl kwaɪətli bæk tə ðə steɪk ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ dɪspaɪt ðə peɪn, hi ɹoʊld ɑntu hɪz niz. ðən i tʊk ðə tɑp ə ði aɪɝn spaɪk ɪn ɪz lɛf hæn ən pʊʃt, hivɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit.

As he finished, he heard voices outside the tent. They were coming for him. He scrabbled quietly back to the stake in the ground. Taking a deep breath despite the pain, he rolled onto his knees. Then he took the top of the iron spike in his left hand and pushed, heaving himself to his feet.

hi wɑbəld, ðən stɛɾid hɪmsɛlf, stændɪŋ ʌp ɔl ðə weɪ. hɪz peɪnz wɝ nʌθɪŋ, naʊ. hi hæd fɛlt ɪnsɛk baɪts ðət wɝ wɝs. hi pʊɾ ɪz fit waɪɾ ɪn ə wɔɹiɝz stæns, hɪz hænz hɛl bɪfɔɹ hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪz ɹɪsts kɹɔst. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz, bæk stʃɹeɪt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tɛn flæps. ɪt wɑzn ðə kloʊk, ðə junəfɔɹm, ðə hɛɹəlʒɹi, əɹ ðə sɔɹd ðət meɪɾ ə mæn. ɪt wɑz ðə weɪ hi hɛl hɪmsɛlf.

He wobbled, then steadied himself, standing up all the way. His pains were nothing, now. He had felt insect bites that were worse. He put his feet wide in a warriors stance, his hands held before himself with his wrists crossed. He opened his eyes, back straight, staring at the tent flaps. It wasn't the cloak, the uniform, the heraldry, or the sword that made a man. It was the way he held himself.

ðə flæps ɹʌsəld, ðən dʒɹu oʊpən. ði aʊtsaɪd laɪt wɑz bɹɪljən tə ɡɑləɾ ɛs aɪz, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt blɪŋk. hi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ.

The flaps rustled, then drew open. The outside light was brilliant to Galad s eyes, but he did not blink. He did not flinch.

sɪləwɛts muvd əɡɛnst ən oʊvɝkæst skaɪ. ðeɪ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bæklɪt. hi kəd tɛl ðeɪ wɝ sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɪm stændɪŋ ðɛɹ.

Silhouettes moved against an overcast sky. They hesitated, backlit. He could tell they were surprised to see him standing there.

"laɪt!" wʌn ɪkskleɪmd. "dəmədʒɹd, haʊ ɪz ɪt ðət jəɹ əweɪk?" ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli, ðə vɔɪs wɑz fəmɪljɝ.

"Light!" one exclaimed. "Damodred, how is it that you're awake?" Unexpectedly, the voice was familiar.

"tʃɹɑm?" ɡɑləɾ æskt, hɪz vɔɪs ɹæɡəd.

"Trom?" Galad asked, his voice ragged.

mɛn spɪld ɪndə ðə ɹum. əz ɪz aɪz ədʒʌstəd, ɡɑləd meɪɾ aʊt stɑki tʃɹɑm, əlɔŋ wɪð bɔɹnhəld ən baɪɑɝ. tʃɹɑm fʌmbəld wɪð ə sɛɾ ə kiz.

Men spilled into the room. As his eyes adjusted, Galad made out stocky Trom, along with Bornhald and Byar. Trom fumbled with a set of keys.

"stɑp!" ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə jə θɹi. bɔɹnhəld, ðəɹ ɪz blʌɾ ɑn jəɹ kloʊk! aɪ kəmændəd jə nɑt tə tʃɹaɪ tə fɹi mi!"

"Stop!" Galad said. "I gave orders to you three. Bornhald, there is blood on your cloak! I commanded you not to try to free me!"

"jɔɹ mɛn oʊbeɪd jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz, dəmədʒɹd," ə nu vɔɪs sɛd. ɡɑləd lʊkt ʌp tə si θɹi mɛn ɛntɝɪŋ ðə ɹum: bɛɹəb ɡəlivɝ, tɔl ən bɪɹɾəd; əlɑbɹ hɑɹnɪʃ, hɪz bɔld, ʃæɾoʊd hɛd mɪsɪŋ ɪts lɛft ɪɹ; bɹændəl vɔɹdɛɹiən, ə blɑn hʌlk ʌv ə mæn fɹəm ɡɑlədz neɪɾɪv ændɝ. ɔl θɹi wɝ lɔɹdz kæptən, ɔl θɹi hæd stʊd wɪð əsunɑwə.

"Your men obeyed your orders, Damodred," a new voice said. Galad looked up to see three men entering the room: Berab Golever, tall and bearded; Alaabar Harnesh, his bald, shadowed head missing its left ear; Brandel Vordarian, a blond hulk of a man from Galad's native Andor. All three were Lords Captain, all three had stood with Asunawa.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" ɡɑləɾ æsk ðɛm.

"What is this?" Galad asked them.

hɑɹnɪʃ oʊpən ə sæk ən dʌmp sʌmθɪŋ bʌlbəs tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɡɑləd. ə hɛd.

Harnesh opened a sack and dumped something bulbous to the ground in front of Galad. A head.

əsunɑwəz.

Asunawa's.

ɔl θɹi mɛn dʒɹu sɔɹdz ən nɛl bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ðə pɔɪns ə ðɛɹ wɛpənz stæbɪŋ ðə kænvəs.

All three men drew swords and knelt before him, the points of their weapons stabbing the canvas.

tʃɹɑm ənlɑk ðə mænəkəlz ət ɡɑlədz fit.

Trom unlocked the manacles at Galad's feet.

"aɪ si," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ju hæv tɝn jəɹ sɔɹdz ɑn fɛloʊ tʃɪlʒɹən."

"I see," Galad said. "You have turned your swords on fellow Children."

"wʌt wəd juv hæɾ əs du?" bɹændəl æskt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ɪz nilɪŋ pəzɪʃən.

"What would you have had us do?" Brandel asked, looking up from his kneeling position.

ɡɑləd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ. pɝhæps jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt; aɪ ʃəd nɑt tʃaɪd jə ɑn ðɪs tʃɔɪs. ɪt meɪ hæv bɪn ði oʊnli wʌn jə kəɾ əv meɪd. bʌt waɪ dɪd jə tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ maɪnz?"

Galad shook his head. "I do not know. Perhaps you are right; I should not chide you on this choice. It may have been the only one you could have made. But why did you change your minds?"

"wi hæv lɔs tu lɔɹdz kæptən kəmændɝ ɪn ʌndɝ hæf ə jɪɹ," hɑɹnɪʃ sɛɾ ɪn ə ɡɹʌf vɔɪs.

"We have lost two Lords Captain Commander in under half a year," Harnesh said in a gruff voice.

"ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪɾ əz bɪkʌm ə pleɪɡɹaʊn fəɹ ðə sintʃæn. ðə wɝld ɪz ɪn keɪɑs."

"The Fortress of the Light has become a playground for the Seanchan. The world is in chaos."

"æn jɛt," ɡəlivɝ sɛd, "əsunɑwə mɑɹtʃt əs ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt hɪɹ tə hæv əs bæɾəl əɹ fɛloʊ tʃɪlʒɹən. ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹaɪt, dəmədʒɹd. wi ɔl sɔ haʊ jə pɹizɛntəd jɝsɛlf, wi ɔl sɔ haʊ jə stɑpt əs fɹəm kɪlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. feɪst wɪð ðæt, ən wɪð ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ neɪmɪŋ əz dɑɹkfɹɛn ə mæn wi ɔl noʊ tə bi ɑnɝəbəl . . . wɛl, haʊ kəd wi nɑt tɝn əɡɛns hɪm?"

"And yet," Golever said, "Asunawa marched us all the way out here to have us battle our fellow Children. It was not right, Damodred. We all saw how you presented yourself, we all saw how you stopped us from killing one another. Faced with that, and with the High Inquisitor naming as Darkfriend a man we all know to be honorable . . . Well, how could we not turn against him?"

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. "ju æksɛp mi əz lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ?"

Galad nodded. "You accept me as Lord Captain Commander?"

ðə θɹi mɛn baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz. "ɔl ðə lɔɹdz kæptən ɑɹ fəɹ ju," ɡəlivɝ sɛd. "wi wɝ fɔɹs tə kɪl ə θɝɾ ə ðoʊz u wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt. səm ʌðɝz junaɪɾəd wɪð ʌs; səm tʃɹaɪd tə fli. ði ɑmɑdɪʃənz dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ, ən mɛni hæv sɛd ðeɪd ɹæðɝ dʒɔɪn wɪð əs ðən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə sintʃæn. wɪv ði ʌðɝ ɑmɑdɪʃənz - ən ðə kwɛstʃənɝz u tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn - hɛld ət sɔɹdpɔɪnt."

The three men bowed their heads. "All the Lords Captain are for you," Golever said. "We were forced to kill a third of those who wore the red shepherd's crook of the Hand of the Light. Some others united with us; some tried to flee. The Amadicians did not interfere, and many have said they'd rather join with us than return to the Seanchan. We have the other Amadicians - and the Questioners who tried to run - held at swordpoint."

"lɛt fɹi ðoʊz u wɪʃ tə liv," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ðeɪ meɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ fæmliz ən ðɛɹ mæstɝz. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃ ðə sintʃæn, wɪl bi bɪɑn ðɛɹ ɡɹæsp."

"Let free those who wish to leave," Galad said. "They may return to their families and their masters. By the time they reach the Seanchan, we will be beyond their grasp."

ðə mɛn nɑɾəd.

The men nodded.

"aɪ æksɛp jəɹ əlidʒəns," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ɡæðɝ ði ʌðɝ lɔɹdz kæptən ən fɛtʃ mi səplaɪ ɹɪpɔɹts. stʃɹaɪk kæmp. wi mɑɹtʃ fəɹ ændɝ."

"I accept your allegiance," Galad said. "Gather the other Lords Captain and fetch me supply reports. Strike camp. We march for Andor."

nʌn ə ðɛm æskt wɛðɝ i niɾəd ɹɛst, ðoʊ tʃɹɑm dɪd lʊk wɝid. ɡɑləɾ æksɛptɪd ðə waɪt ɹoʊb ə tʃaɪl bɹɔt tə hɪm, ən ðən sæɾ ɪn ə heɪstəli səplaɪd tʃɛɹ əz ənʌðɝ-tʃaɪl kændiɑɝ, ə mæn ɛkspɝɾ ɪn wunz ɛntɝd tə ɪnspɛkt ɪz ɪnʒɝiz. ɡɑləd dɪdn fil waɪz əɹ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bɛɹ ðə taɪɾəl i dɪd.

None of them asked whether he needed rest, though Trom did look worried. Galad accepted the white robe a Child brought to him, and then sat in a hastily supplied chair as another-Child Candeiar, a man expert in wounds entered to inspect his injuries. Galad didn't feel wise or strong enough to bear the title he did.

bʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən hæd meɪd ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒən. ðə laɪt wəd pɹətɛkt əm fəɹ ɪt.

But the Children had made their decision. The light would protect them for it.


tʃæptɝ θɹi


CHAPTER 3

ði ɑɹnɪɹlɪnz æŋɡɝ


The Arnyrlin's Anger

ɛɡwin floʊɾəd ɪn blæknəs. ʃi wɑz wɪθaʊt fɔɹm, lækɪŋ ʃeɪp əɹ bɑɾi. ðə θɔts, ɪmædʒɪnɪŋz, wɝiz, hoʊps, ən aɪdiəz ʌv ɔl ðə wɝld ɪkstɛndəɾ ɪndə ɪtɝnəɾi ɝaʊn hɝ.

Egwene floated in blackness. She was without form, lacking shape or body. The thoughts, imaginings, worries, hopes, and ideas of all the world extended into eternity around her.

ðɪs wɑz ðə pleɪs bɪtwin dʒɹimz ən ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld, ə blæknəs pɪnpɹɪkt wɪð θaʊzənz əpɑn θaʊzənz ə dɪstɪŋk laɪts, itʃ mɔɹ foʊkəst ən ɪntɛns ðən ðə stɑɹz ə ðə skaɪz. ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹimz, ən ʃi kəd lʊk ɪn ɑn ðɛm, bʌt dɪd nɑt. ðə wʌnz ʃi wɑntəd tə si wɝ wɔɹɾɪd, ən moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz wɝ mɪstɝiz tə hɝ.

This was the place between dreams and the waking world, a blackness pinpricked with thousands upon thousands of distinct lights, each more focused and intense than the stars of the skies. They were dreams, and she could look in on them, but did not. The ones she wanted to see were warded, and most of the others were mysteries to her.

ðəɹ wɑz wʌn dʒɹim ʃi lɔŋ tə slɪp ɪntu. ʃi ɹistʃɹeɪn hɝsɛlf. ðoʊ hɝ filɪŋz fəɹ ɡɔɪn wɝ stɪl stʃɹɔŋ, hɝ əpɪnjən ə hɪm wɑz mʌɾəld ɹisənli. ɡɛɾɪŋ lɔst ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz wəd nɑt hɛlp.

There was one dream she longed to slip into. She restrained herself. Though her feelings for Gawyn were still strong, her opinion of him was muddled recently. Getting lost in his dreams would not help.

ʃi tɝn əbaʊt, lʊkɪŋ θɹu ði ɪkspæns. ɹisənli, ʃid stɑɹɾəd kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ tə floʊɾ ən θɪŋk. ðə dʒɹimz ʌv ɔl ðə pipəl hɪɹ - səm fɹəm əɹ wɝld, səm fɹəm ʃædoʊz ʌv ɪt - ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ waɪ ʃi fɔt. ʃi mʌs nɛvɝ fɝɡɛt ðət ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪntaɪɝ wɝld aʊtsaɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝz wɔlz. ðə pɝpəs ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz tə sɝv ðət wɝld.

She turned about, looking through the expanse. Recently, she'd started coming here to float and think. The dreams of all the people here - some from her world, some from shadows of it - reminded her why she fought. She must never forget that there was an entire world outside the White Tower's walls. The purpose of Aes Sedai was to serve that world.

taɪm pæst əz ʃi leɪ beɪðd ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə dʒɹimz. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi wɪl hɝsɛlf tə muv, ən loʊkeɪɾəd ə dʒɹim ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd - ðoʊ ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ ʃi dɪɾ ɪt. ðə dʒɹim swɛpt ʌp təwɔɹd hɝ, fɪlɪŋ əɹ vɪʒən.

Time passed as she lay bathed in the light of dreams. Eventually, she willed herself to move, and located a dream she recognized - though she wasn't certain how she did it. The dream swept up toward her, filling her vision.

ʃi pɹɛst əɹ wɪl əɡɛns ðə dʒɹim ən sɛn ə θɔɾ ɪndə ɪt. nɪneɪiv. ɪts taɪm tə stɑp əvɔɪɾɪŋ mi. ðəɹ ɪz wɝk tə bi dʌn, ən aɪ hæv nuz fəɹ ju. mit mi ɪn tu naɪts ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ɪf jə də nɑt kʌm, əl bi fɔɹs tə teɪk mɛʒɝz. jəɹ dæliəns θɹɛɾənz əs ɔl.

She pressed her will against the dream and sent a thought into it. Nynaeve. It is time to stop avoiding me. There is work to be done, and I have news for you. Meet me in two nights in the Hall of the Tower. If you do not come, I will be forced to take measures. Your dalliance threatens us all.

ðə dʒɹim sim tə ʃʌɾɝ, ən ɛɡwin pʊl bæk əz ɪt vænɪʃt. ʃiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi spoʊkən tə ɪleɪn. ðoʊz tu wɝ lus θɹɛdz; ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi tʃɹuli ɹeɪz tə ðə ʃɔl, wɪð ði oʊðz ədmɪnəstɝd.

The dream seemed to shudder, and Egwene pulled back as it vanished. She'd already spoken to Elayne. Those two were loose threads; they needed to be truly raised to the shawl, with the oaths administered.

bɪɑn ðæt, ɛɡwin niɾəd ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm nɪneɪiv. hoʊpfəli, ðə θɹɛt mɪkst wɪð ə pɹɑməs ə nuz wəd bɹɪŋ hɝ. ən ðət nuz wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə waɪt taʊɝ faɪnəli junəfaɪd, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɪkjʊɹ, ɪleɪɾə kæptʃɝd baɪ ðə sintʃæn.

Beyond that, Egwene needed information from Nynaeve. Hopefully, the threat mixed with a promise of news would bring her. And that news was important. The White Tower finally unified, the Amyrlin Seat secure, Elaida captured by the Seanchan.

pɪnpɹɪk dʒɹimz stʃɹikt ɝaʊn ɛɡwin. ʃi kənsɪɾɝd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɑntæk ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌt dɪsaɪɾɪd əɡɛnst ɪt. haʊ ʃəd ʃi dil wɪð ðɛm? ðə fɝs θɪŋ wɑz tə kip əm fɹəm θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ "dɛlt wɪð." hɝ plæn fəɹ əm wɑz nɑt jɛt fɝm.

Pinprick dreams streaked around Egwene. She considered trying to contact the Wise Ones, but decided against it. How should she deal with them? The first thing was to keep them from thinking they were being "dealt with." Her plan for them was not yet firm.

ʃi lɛt hɝsɛlf slɪp bæk ɪndə hɝ bɑɾi, kɑntɛn tə spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə ðə naɪt wɪð əɹ oʊn dʒɹimz.

She let herself slip back into her body, content to spend the rest of the night with her own dreams.

hɪɹ, ʃi kʊdn kip θɔts ʌv ɡɔɪn fɹəm vɪzəɾɪŋ hɝ, nɔɹ dɪd ʃi wɑn tə. ʃi stɛpt ɪndə hɝ dʒɹim, ən ɪndə hɪz ɛmbɹeɪs. ðeɪ stʊɾ ɪn ə smɔl stoʊn-wɔld ɹum ʃeɪp laɪk əɹ stʌɾi ɪn ðə taʊɝ, jɛt dɛkɝeɪɾəd laɪk ðə kɑmən ɹum ə hɝ fɑðɝz ɪn. ɡɔɪn wɑz dʒɹɛst ɪn stɝɾi tu ɹɪvɝz wʊlənz ən dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ɪz sɔɹd. ə mɔɹ sɪmpəl laɪf. ɪt kəd nɑt bi hɝz, bʌt ʃi kəd dʒɹim . . .

Here, she couldn't keep thoughts of Gawyn from visiting her, nor did she want to. She stepped into her dream, and into his embrace. They stood in a small stone-walled room shaped like her study in the Tower, yet decorated like the common room of her fathers inn. Gawyn was dressed in sturdy Two Rivers woolens and did not wear his sword. A more simple life. It could not be hers, but she could dream . . .

ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃʊk. ðə ɹum ə pæst ən pɹɛzən sim tə ʃæɾɝ, ʃɹɛɾɪŋ ɪndə swɝlɪŋ smoʊk.

Everything shook. The room of past and present seemed to shatter, shredding into swirling smoke.

ɛɡwin stɛp bæk, ɡæspɪŋ, əz ɡɔɪn ɹɪpt əpɑɹɾ əz ɪf meɪɾ ə sænd. ɔl wɑz dʌst ɝaʊn hɝ, ən θɝtin blæk taʊɝz ɹoʊz ɪn ðə dɪstəns bɪniθ ə tɑɹlaɪk skaɪ.

Egwene stepped back, gasping, as Gawyn ripped apart as if made of sand. All was dust around her, and thirteen black towers rose in the distance beneath a tarlike sky.

wʌn fɛl, ən ðən ənʌðɝ, kɹæʃɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. əz ðeɪ dɪd, ðə wʌnz ðət ɹɪmeɪnd ɡɹu tɔlɝ ən tɔlɝ. ðə ɡɹaʊnd ʃʊk əz sɛvɹəl mɔɹ taʊɝz fɛl. ənʌðɝ taʊɝ ʃʊk ən kɹækt, kəlæpsɪŋ moʊst ə ðə weɪ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd - bʌt ðɛn, ɪt ɹəkʌvɝɾ ən ɡɹu tɔlɪst ʌv ɔl.

One fell, and then another, crashing to the ground. As they did, the ones that remained grew taller and taller. The ground shook as several more towers fell. Another tower shook and cracked, collapsing most of the way to the ground - but then, it recovered and grew tallest of all.

ət ði ɛn ə ðə kweɪk, sɪks taʊɝz ɹɪmeɪnd, lumɪŋ əbʌv hɝ. ɛɡwin hæd fɔlən tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɪtʃ hæd bɪkʌm sɑft ɝθ kʌvɝɾ ɪn wɪðɝd livz. ðə vɪʒən tʃeɪnʒd. ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ ə nɛst. ɪn ɪt, ə ɡɹup ə flɛdʒlɪŋ iɡəlz skɹitʃt təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ fəɹ ðɛɹ mʌðɝ.

At the end of the quake, six towers remained, looming above her. Egwene had fallen to the ground, which had become soft earth covered in withered leaves. The vision changed. She was looking down at a nest. In it, a group of fledgling eagles screeched toward the sky for their mother.

wʌn ə ði iɡələts ʌnkɔɪld, ən ɪt wɑzn ən iɡəl əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ ə sɝpənt. ɪt bɪɡæn tə stʃɹaɪk ət ðə flɛdʒəlɪŋz wʌn əɾ ə taɪm, swɑloʊɪŋ əm hoʊl. ði iɡələts sɪmpli kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ ɪndə ðə skaɪ, pɹitɛndɪŋ ðət ðə sɝpənt wɑz ðɛɹ sɪblɪŋ əz ɪt dɪvaʊɝd ðɛm.

One of the eaglets uncoiled, and it wasn't an eagle at all, but a serpent. It began to strike at the fledglings one at a time, swallowing them whole. The eaglets simply continued to stare into the sky, pretending that the serpent was their sibling as it devoured them.

ðə vɪʒən tʃeɪnʒd. ʃi sɔ ən ɪnɔɹməs sfɪɹ meɪɾ ə ðə faɪnəs kɹɪstəl. ɪt spɑɹkəld ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə twɛnti-θɹi ɪnɔɹməs stɑɹz, ʃaɪnɪŋ daʊn ɑn ɪt wɛɹ ɪt sæɾ ɑn ə dɑɹk hɪltɑp. ðəɹ wɝ kɹæks ɪn ɪt, ən ɪt wɑz biɪŋ hɛl təɡɛðɝ baɪ ɹoʊps.

The vision changed. She saw an enormous sphere made of the finest crystal. It sparkled in the light of twenty-three enormous stars, shining down on it where it sat on a dark hilltop. There were cracks in it, and it was being held together by ropes.

ðəɹ wɑz ɹænd, wɔkɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪlsaɪd, hoʊldɪŋ ə wʊdzmənz æks. hi ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ən hɛftəd ði æks, ðən swʌŋ ət ðə ɹoʊps wʌn əɾ ə ɹaɪm, tʃɑpɪŋ əm fɹi. ðə læst wʌn pɑɹɾəd, ən ðə sfɪɹ bɪɡæn tə bɹeɪk əpɑɹt, ðə bjuɾəfəl ɡloʊb fɔlɪŋ ɪn pisəz. ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

There was Rand, walking up the hillside, holding a woodsman's axe. He reached the top and hefted the axe, then swung at the ropes one at a rime, chopping them free. The last one parted, and the sphere began to break apart, the beautiful globe falling in pieces. Rand shook his head.

ɛɡwin ɡæspt, keɪm əweɪk, ən sæɾ əpɹaɪt. ʃi wɑz ɪn əɹ ɹumz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ wɑz nɪɹli ɛmpti - ʃid hæɾ ɪleɪɾəz θɪŋz ɹimuvd, bʌt hædn kəmplitli fɝnɪʃt ɪɾ əɡɛn. ʃi hæɾ oʊnli ə wɑʃstænd, ə ɹʌɡ ʌv θɪk-woʊvən bɹaʊn faɪbɝz, ən ə bɛd wɪð poʊsts ən dʒɹeɪps.

Egwene gasped, came awake, and sat upright. She was in her rooms in the White Tower. The bedchamber was nearly empty - she'd had Elaida's things removed, but hadn't completely furnished it again. She had only a washstand, a rug of thick-woven brown fibers, and a bed with posts and drapes.

ðə wɪndoʊ ʃʌɾɝz wɝ kloʊzd; mɔɹnɪŋ sʌnlaɪt pik θɹu.

The window shutters were closed; morning sunlight peeked through.

ʃi bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt. ɹɛɹli dɪd dʒɹimz ənsɛɾəl əɹ əz mʌtʃ əz ðɪs wʌn hæd.

She breathed in and out. Rarely did dreams unsettle her as much as this one had.

kɑmɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ʃi ɹitʃt daʊn tə ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ bɛd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə lɛðɝ-baʊn bʊk ʃi kɛp ðəɹ tə ɹəkɔɹɾ əɹ dʒɹimz. ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə θɹi ðɪs naɪt wɑz ðə klɪɹɪs tə hɝ. ʃi fɛl ðə minɪŋ ʌv ɪt, ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ əz ʃi səmtaɪmz kʊd. ðə sɝpənt wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, hɪɾən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɛɡwin hæd səspɛktəd ðɪs wɑz ðə keɪs - vɛɹɪn hæd sɛd ʃi bɪlivd ɪt soʊ.

Calming herself, she reached down to the side of her bed, picking up the leather-bound book she kept there to record her dreams. The middle of the three this night was the clearest to her. She felt the meaning of it, interpreting it as she sometimes could. The serpent was one of the Forsaken, hidden in the White Tower, pretending to be Aes Sedai. Egwene had suspected this was the case - Verin had said she believed it so.

mɛsænə wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. bʌt haʊ dɪd ʃi ɪməteɪɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɛvɹi sɪstɝ hæd ɹɪswɔɹn ði oʊðz. əpɛɹənli mɛsænə kəd dɪfit ði oʊθ ɹɑd. əz ɛɡwin kɛɹfəli ɹəkɔɹɾəd ðə dʒɹimz, ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt ðə taʊɝz, lumɪŋ, θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɝ, ən ʃi nu səm ə ðə minɪŋ ðəɹ tu.

Mesaana was still in the White Tower. But how did she imitate an Aes Sedai? Every sister had resworn the oaths. Apparently Mesaana could defeat the Oath Rod. As Egwene carefully recorded the dreams, she thought about the towers, looming, threatening to destroy her, and she knew some of the meaning there too.

ɪf ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt faɪn mɛsænə ən stɑp hɝ, sʌmθɪŋ tɛɹəbəl wəd hæpən. ɪt kəd min ðə fɔl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, pɝhæps ðə vɪktɝi ʌv ðə dɑɹk wʌn. dʒɹimz wɝ nɑt fɔɹtɛlɪŋz - ðeɪ dɪdnt ʃoʊ wʌt wəd hæpən, bʌt wʌt kʊd.

If Egwene did not find Mesaana and stop her, something terrible would happen. It could mean the fall of the White Tower, perhaps the victory of the Dark One. Dreams were not Foretellings - they didn't show what would happen, but what could.

laɪt, ʃi θɔt, fɪnɪʃɪŋ əɹ ɹɛkɝd. əz ɪf aɪ dɪdn əv ɪnʌf tə wɝi əbaʊt.

Light, she thought, finishing her record. As if I didn't have enough to worry about.

ɛɡwin ɹoʊz tə kɔl əɹ meɪdz, bʌɾ ə nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ ɪntɝʌptɪd hɝ. kjʊɹiəs, ʃi wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə θɪk ɹʌɡ - wɛɹɪŋ oʊnli hɝ naɪtɡaʊn -  ən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ɪnʌf tə si sɪlviænə stændɪŋ ɪn ði æntətʃæmbɝ. skwɛɹ-fitʃɝɾ ən dʒɹɛst ɪn ɹɛd, ʃi hæɾ əɹ hɛɹ ʌp ɪn ɪts tɪpəkəl bʌn, ən əɹ ɹɛd kipɝz stoʊl oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

Egwene rose to call her maids, but a knock at the door interrupted her. Curious, she walked across the thick rug - wearing only her nightgown -  and opened the door enough to see Silviana standing in the antechamber. Square-featured and dressed in red, she had her hair up in its typical bun, and her red Keeper's stole over her shoulders.

'mʌðɝ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs tɛns. "aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ weɪkɪŋ ju."

'Mother," the woman said, her voice tense. "I apologize for waking you."

"aɪ wɑzn əslip," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt? wʌɾ əz hæpənd?"

"I wasn't asleep," Egwene said. "What is it? What has happened?"

"hiz hɪɹ, mʌðɝ. ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"He's here, Mother. At the White Tower."

"hu?"

"Who?"

"ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hiz æskɪŋ tə si ju."

"The Dragon Reborn. He's asking to see you."

* * * "wɛl, ðɪs ɪz ə pɑɾ ə fɪʃɝmænz stu meɪɾ oʊnli wɪð ðə hɛdz," sɪuən sɛɾ əz ʃi stɔk θɹu ə hɔlweɪ ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ. "haʊ dɪɾ i ɡɛt θɹu ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn siɪŋ hɪm?"

* * * "Well, this is a pot of fisherman's stew made only with the heads," Siuan said as she stalked through a hallway of the White Tower. "How did he get through the city without anyone seeing him?"

haɪ kæptən tʃʌbn wɪnst.

High Captain Chubain winced.

əz wɛl i ʃʊd, sɪuən θɔt. ðə ɹeɪvən-hɛɹd mæn wɔɹ ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd, ə waɪt tɑbɝɾ oʊvɝ ɪz meɪl ɛmbleɪzənd wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. hi wɔkt wɪð ə hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. ðəɹ hæd bɪn səm tɔk ðəɾ i maɪt bi ɹipleɪst əz haɪ kæptən naʊ ðət bɹaɪn wɑz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd fɑloʊd sɪuənz ædvaɪs nɑt tə də soʊ. bɹaɪn dɪdnt wɑnə bi haɪ kæptən, ən i wəd bi niɾəd əz ə fil dʒɛnɝəl fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

As well he should, Siuan thought. The raven-haired man wore the uniform of the Tower Guard, a white tabard over his mail emblazoned with the flame of Tar Valon. He walked with a hand on his sword. There had been some talk that he might be replaced as High Captain now that Bryne was in Tar Valon, but Egwene had followed Siuan's advice not to do so. Bryne didn't want to be High Captain, and he would be needed as a field general for the Last Battle.

bɹaɪn wɑz aʊt wɪð ɪz mɛn; faɪndɪŋ kɔɹɾɝz ən fud fəɹ fɪfti θaʊzən tʃɹups wɑz pɹuvɪŋ tə bi nɪɹ ɪmpɑsəbəl. ʃid sɛn ɪm wɝd, ən kəd fil ɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊsɝ. stɝn blɑk ʌv wʊd ðoʊ ðə mæn wɑz, sɪuən fɛl ðəɾ ɪz stəbɪlɪɾi wʊɾə bɪn naɪs tə hæv nɪɹ əɹ ɹaɪt naʊ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ɪnsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn?

Bryne was out with his men; finding quarters and food for fifty thousand troops was proving to be near impossible. She'd sent him word, and could feel him getting closer. Stern block of wood though the man was, Siuan felt that his stability would have been nice to have near her right now. The Dragon Reborn? Inside Tar Valon?

"ɪts nɑt ɹɪli ðət sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ i ɡɑt soʊ fɑɹ, sɪuən," sɹɪn sɛd. ði ɑləv-skɪn bɹaʊn hæd bɪn wɪð sɪuən wən ðeɪd sin ðə kæptən ɹeɪsɪŋ baɪ, peɪl-feɪst. sɹɪn hæd waɪɾ əɾ əɹ tɛmpəlz, səm mɛʒɝ ʌv eɪdʒ əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən hæɾ ə skɑɹ ɑn wʌn tʃik, ði ɔɹədʒən ʌv wɪtʃ sɪuən hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə pɹaɪ aʊɾ ə hɝ.

"It's not really that surprising he got so far, Siuan," Saerin said. The olive-skinned Brown had been with Siuan when they'd seen the captain racing by, pale-faced. Saerin had white at her temples, some measure of age as an Aes Sedai, and had a scar on one cheek, the origin of which Siuan hadn't been able to pry out of her.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə ɹɛfjudʒiz pɔɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi itʃ deɪ," sɹɪn kəntɪnjud, "æn ɛni mæn wɪð hæf ən ɪnkləneɪʃən tə faɪɾ ɪz biɪŋ sɛn fəɹ ɹəkɹutmən ɪndə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd. ɪts noʊ wʌndɝ noʊbɑdi stɑpt ælθɹ."

"There are hundreds of refugees pouring into the city each day," Saerin continued, "and any man with half an inclination to fight is being sent for recruitment into the Tower Guard. It's no wonder nobody stopped al'Thor."

tʃʌbn nɑɾəd. "hi wɑz ət ðə sʌnsɛt ɡeɪt bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kwɛstʃən hɪm. ən ðən i dʒʌst . . .

Chubain nodded. "He was at the Sunset Gate before anyone questioned him. And then he just . . .

wɛl, hi dʒʌst sɛɾ i wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə si ði æmɪɝlɪn. dɪdn jɛl ɪɾ aʊɾ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ, sɛɾ ɪt kɑm əz spɹɪŋ ɹeɪn."

well, he just said he was the Dragon Reborn, and that he wanted to see the Amyrlin. Didn't yell it out or anything, said it calm as spring rain."

ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə taʊɝ wɝ bɪzi, ðoʊ moʊst ə ðə wɪmən dɪdn sim tə noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ tə du, dɑɹɾɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðət laɪk fɪʃ ɪn ə nɛt.

The hallways of the Tower were busy, though most of the women didn't seem to know what they were to do, darting this way and that like fish in a net.

stɑp ðæt, sɪuən θɔt. hiz kʌm ɪndə əɹ siɾ ə paʊɝ. hiz ðə wʌn kɑɾ ɪn ðə nɛt.

Stop that, Siuan thought. He's come into our seat of power. He's the one caught in the net.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪz ɡeɪm, dʒju θɪŋk?" sɹɪn æskt.

"What is his game, do you think?" Saerin asked.

"bɝn mi ɪf aɪ noʊ," sɪuən ɹɪplaɪd. "hiz baʊn tə bi moʊsli ɪnseɪn baɪ naʊ. meɪbi hiz fɹaɪɾənd, ən əz kʌm tə tɝn hɪmsɛlf ɪn."

"Burn me if I know," Siuan replied. "He's bound to be mostly insane by now. Maybe he's frightened, and has come to turn himself in."

"aɪ daʊt ðæt."

"I doubt that."

'æz də aɪ," sɪuən sɛd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. dʊɹɪŋ ðiz læs fju deɪz, ʃid faʊnd - tə hɝ əmeɪzmənt - ðət ʃi laɪk sɹɪn. əz æmɪɝlɪn, sɪuən hædn hæd taɪm fəɹ fɹɛndʃɪps; ɪt hæd bɪn tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə pleɪ ði ədʒəz ɔf wʌn ənʌðɝ. ʃid θɔt sɹɪn ɑbstənəɾ ən fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ. naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝn bʌɾɪŋ hɛdz soʊ ɔfən, ʃi faʊn ðoʊz ætʃɹəbjuts əpilɪŋ.

'As do I," Siuan said grudgingly. During these last few days, she'd found - to her amazement - that she liked Saerin. As Amyrlin, Siuan hadn't had time for friendships; it had been too important to play the Ajahs off one another. She'd thought Saerin obstinate and frustrating. Now that they weren't butting heads so often, she found those attributes appealing.

"meɪbi hi hɝd ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɡɔn," sɪuən sɛd, "æn θɔt ðəɾ i wəd bi seɪf hɪɹ, wɪð ən oʊl fɹɛn ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

"Maybe he heard that Elaida was gone," Siuan said, "and thought that he would be safe here, with an old friend on the Amyrlin Seat."

"ðæt dʌzn mætʃ wʌɾ aɪv ɹɛɾ ə ðə bɔɪ," sɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɹɪpɔɹts kɔl ɪm mɪstʃɹʌsfəl ən ɪɹæɾɪk, wɪð ə dɪmændɪŋ tɛmpɝ ən ən ɪnsɪstəns ɑn əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"That doesn't match what I've read of the boy," Saerin replied. "Reports call him mistrustful and erratic, with a demanding temper and an insistence on avoiding Aes Sedai."

ðət wɑz wʌt sɪuən hæd hɝɾ əz wɛl, ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn tu jɪɹz sɪns ʃid sin ðə bɔɪ. ɪn fækt, ðə læs taɪm hid stʊd bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ʃid bɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn ən hid bɪn ə sɪmpəl ʃifɝɾɝ.

That was what Siuan had heard as well, though it had been two years since she'd seen the boy. In fact, the last time he'd stood before her, she'd been the Amyrlin and he'd been a simple sheepherder.

moʊst ʌv wʌt ʃi nu ʌv ɪm sɪns ðən hæd kʌm θɹu ðə blu ədʒɑz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz. ɪt tʊk ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə skɪl tə sɛpɝeɪt spɛkjəleɪʃən fɹəm tʃɹuθ, bʌt moʊst əɡɹiɾ əbaʊɾ ælθɹ. tɛmpɹəmɛntəl, dɪstʃɹʌsfəl, ɛɹəɡənt. laɪt bɝn ɪleɪɾə! sɪuən θɔt. ɪf nɑt fəɹ hɝ, wiɾ əv hæɾ ɪm seɪfli ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ kɛɹ lɔŋ əɡoʊ.

Most of what she knew of him since then had come through the Blue Ajah's eyes-and-ears. It took a great deal of skill to separate speculation from truth, but most agreed about al'Thor. Temperamental, distrustful, arrogant. Light burn Elaida! Siuan thought. If not for her, we'd have had him safely in Aes Sedai care long ago.

ðeɪ klaɪm daʊn θɹi spaɪɹəlɪŋ ɹæmps ən ɛntɝɾ ənʌðɝ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝz waɪt-wɔl hɔlweɪz, muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz gɑnə ɹəsiv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðən ʃid də ɪt ðɛɹ. tu twɪstɪŋ tɝnz leɪɾɝ - pæs mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps ən steɪtli tæpəstʃɹiz - ðeɪ ɛntɝd wʌn læs hɔlweɪ ən fɹoʊz.

They climbed down three spiraling ramps and entered another of the White Tower's white-walled hallways, moving toward the Hall of the Tower. If the Amyrlin was going to receive the Dragon Reborn, then she'd do it there. Two twisting turns later - past mirrored stand-lamps and stately tapestries - they entered one last hallway and froze.

ðə flɔɹ taɪlz hɪɹ wɝ ðə kʌlɝ ə blʌd. ðət wɑzn ɹaɪt. ðə wʌnz hɪɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn waɪɾ ən jɛloʊ. ðiz ɡlɪsənd, əz ɪf wɛt.

The floor tiles here were the color of blood. That wasn't right. The ones here should have been white and yellow. These glistened, as if wet.

tʃʌbn ɪnheɪld ʃɑɹpli, hænd ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. sɹɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. sɪuən wɑz tɛmptəd tə bæɹəl ɔnwɝd, bʌt ðiz pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd tʌtʃt ðə wɝl kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs. ʃi maɪt faɪn hɝsɛlf sɪŋkɪŋ θɹu ðə flɔɹ, əɹ biɪŋ ətæk baɪ ðə tæpəstʃɹiz.

Chubain inhaled sharply, hand going to his sword hilt. Saerin raised an eyebrow. Siuan was tempted to barrel onward, but these places where the Dark One had touched the world could be dangerous. She might find herself sinking through the floor, or being attacked by the tapestries.

ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ tɝn ən wɔk ði ʌðɝ weɪ. tʃʌbn lɪŋɡɝd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən hɝiɾ æftɝ. ɪt wɑz izi tə ɹid ðə tɛnʃən ɪn ɪz feɪs. fɝs ðə sintʃæn, ən naʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf, kʌm tə əsɔl ðə taʊɝ ɑn ɪz wɑtʃ.

The two Aes Sedai turned and walked the other way. Chubain lingered for a moment, then hurried after. It was easy to read the tension in his face. First the Seanchan, and now the Dragon Reborn himself, come to assault the Tower on his watch.

əz ðeɪ pæs θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz, ðeɪ mɛɾ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz floʊɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən. moʊst ə ðɛm wɔɹ ðɛɹ ʃɔlz. wʌn maɪɾ əv ɑɹɡjud ðət wɑz kəz ə ðə nuz ə ðə deɪ, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz ðət mɛni stɪl hɛl tə ðɛɹ dɪstʃɹʌst ʌv ʌðɝ ədʒəz. ənʌðɝ ɹizən tə kɝs ɪleɪɾə. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ hɑɹd tə ɹɪfɔɝdʒ ðə taʊɝ, bʌt wʌn kʊdn mɛn jɪɹz' wɝθ ə bɹoʊkən nɛts ɪn wʌn mʌnθ.

As they passed through the hallways, they met other sisters flowing in the same direction. Most of them wore their shawls. One might have argued that was because of the news of the day, but the truth was that many still held to their distrust of other Ajahs. Another reason to curse Elaida. Egwene had been working hard to reforge the Tower, but one couldn't mend years' worth of broken nets in one month.

ðeɪ faɪnəli ɝaɪvd ət ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. sɪstɝz klʌstɝɾ ɪn ðə waɪd hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd, dɪvaɪɾəd baɪ ədʒɑ. tʃʌbn hɝid tə spik wɪð ɪz ɡɑɹdz ət ðə dɔɹ, ən sɹɪn ɛntɝd ðə hɔl pɹɑpɝ, wɛɹ ʃi kəd weɪt wɪð ði ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz. sɪuən ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ wɪð ðə dʌzənz aʊtsaɪd.

They finally arrived at the Hall of the Tower. Sisters clustered in the wide hallway outside, divided by Ajah. Chubain hurried to speak with his guards at the door, and Saerin entered the Hall proper, where she could wait with the other Sitters. Siuan remained standing with the dozens outside.

θɪŋz wɝ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ɛɡwin hæɾ ə nu kipɝ tə ɹipleɪs ʃɛɹiɑɹn. ðə tʃɔɪs ə sɪlviænə meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə sɛns - ðə wʊmən wɑz noʊn tə hæv ə lɛvəl hɛd, fəɹ ə ɹɛd, ən tʃuzɪŋ əɹ hæd hɛlp fɔɹdʒ ðə tu hævz ə ðə taʊɝ bæk təɡɛðɝ. bʌt sɪuən hæd hɑɹbɝɾ ə smɔl hoʊp ðət ʃi hɝsɛlf wəd bi tʃoʊzən. naʊ ɛɡwin hæd soʊ mɛni dɪmænz ɑn əɹ taɪm - ən wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ soʊ keɪpəbəl ɑn əɹ oʊn - ðət ʃi wɑz ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn sɪuən lɛs ən lɛs.

Things were changing. Egwene had a new Keeper to replace Sheriarn. The choice of Silviana made a great deal of sense - the woman was known to have a level head, for a Red, and choosing her had helped forge the two halves of the Tower back together. But Siuan had harbored a small hope that she herself would be chosen. Now Egwene had so many demands on her time - and was becoming so capable on her own - that she was relying on Siuan less and less.

ðət wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ.

That was a good thing. But it was also infuriating.

ðə fəmɪljɝ hɔlweɪz, ðə sɛn ə fɹɛʃli wɑʃt stoʊn, ði ɛkoʊɪŋ ə fʊtstɛps . . . wən læst ʃid bɪn ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, ʃid kəmændəɾ ɪt. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ.

The familiar hallways, the scent of freshly washed stone, the echoing of footsteps . . . When last she'd been in this place, she'd commanded it. No longer.

ʃi hæd noʊ maɪn tə klaɪm əɹ weɪ ɪndə pɹɑmənəns əɡɛn. ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz əpɑn ðɛm; ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə spɛn əɹ taɪm dilɪŋ wɪð ðə skwɑbəlz ə ðə blu ədʒɑ əz ðeɪ ɹiɪntəɡɹeɪɾɪd ɪndə ðə taʊɝ. ʃi wɑntəd tə də wʌt ʃid sɛɾ aʊt tə du, ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃɛpɝd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tə ðə læs bæɾəl.

She had no mind to climb her way into prominence again. The Last Battle was upon them; she didn't want to spend her time dealing with the squabbles of the Blue Ajah as they reintegrated into the Tower. She wanted to do what she'd set out to do, all those years before with Moiraine. Shepherd the Dragon Reborn to the Last Battle.

θɹu ðə bɑnd, ʃi fɛl bɹaɪn ɝaɪv bɪfɔɹ i spoʊk. "naʊ, ðɛɹz ə kənsɝn feɪs," hi sɛd, pɪɹsɪŋ ðə hɔlweɪz dʌzənz ə hʌʃt kɑnvɝseɪʃənz əz i wɔkt ʌp bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Through the bond, she felt Bryne arrive before he spoke. "Now, there's a concerned face," he said, piercing the hallways dozens of hushed conversations as he walked up behind her.

sɪuən tɝn tə hɪm. hi wɑz steɪtli ən ɹɪmɑɹkəbli kɑm - pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli fəɹ ə mæn u hæd bɪn bɪtʃɹeɪd baɪ mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, ðən sʌkt ɪndə ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑlətɪks, ðən toʊld i wɑz gɑnə bi liɾɪŋ ɪz tʃɹups ɑn ðə fɹʌn laɪnz ə ðə læs bæɾəl. bʌt ðət wɑz bɹaɪn. sɝin tə ə fɔlt. hi suðd əɹ wɝiz dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ ðɛɹ.

Siuan turned to him. He was stately and remarkably calm - particularly for a man who had been betrayed by Morgase Trakand, then sucked into Aes Sedai politics, then told he was going to be leading his troops on the front lines of the Last Battle. But that was Bryne. Serene to a fault. He soothed her worries just by being there.

"ju keɪm fæstɝ ðən aɪɾ əsum jud bi eɪbəl tə," ʃi sɛd. "æn aɪ də nɑɾ əv ə 'kənsɝn feɪs,' ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ. maɪ vɛɹi neɪtʃɝ ɪz tə bi ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə maɪsɛlf ən maɪ sɝaʊndɪŋz."

"You came faster than I'd assumed you'd be able to," she said. "And I do not have a 'concerned face,' Gareth Bryne. I'm Aes Sedai. My very nature is to be in control of myself and my surroundings."

"jɛs," hi sɛd. "æn jɛt, ðə mɔɹ taɪm aɪ spɛn ɝaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə mɔɹ aɪ wʌndɝ əbaʊt ðæt. ɑɹ ðeɪ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðɛɹ ɪmoʊʃənz? əɹ də ðoʊz ɪmoʊʃənz dʒʌs nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒ? ɪf wʌn ɪz ɔlweɪz kənsɝnd, wʌn wɪl ɔlweɪz lʊk ðə seɪm."

"Yes," he said. "And yet, the more time I spend around the Aes Sedai, the more I wonder about that. Are they in control of their emotions? Or do those emotions just never change? If one is always concerned, one will always look the same."

ʃi aɪd hɪm. "ful mæn."

She eyed him. "Fool man."

hi smaɪld, tɝnɪŋ tə lʊk θɹu ðə hɔlweɪ fʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz. "aɪ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ wɪð ə ɹipɔɹt wən jəɹ mɛsənʒɝ faʊn mi. θæŋk ju."

He smiled, turning to look through the hallway full of Aes Sedai and Warders. "I was already returning to the Tower with a report when your messenger found me. Thank you."

"jɔɹ wɛlkəm," ʃi sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ.

"You're welcome," she said gruffly.

"ðeɪɹ nɝvəs," hi sɛd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪv ɛvɝ sin ði ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪk ðɪs."

"They're nervous," he said. "I don't think I've ever seen the Aes Sedai like this."

"wɛl, kən jə bleɪm ʌs?" ʃi snæpt.

"Well, can you blame us?" she snapped.

hi lʊkt ət hɝ, ðən ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz stʃɹɔŋ, kælʌz fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt əɹ nɛk. "wʌɾ ɪz ɹɔŋ?"

He looked at her, then raised a hand to her shoulder. His strong, callused fingers brushed her neck. "What is wrong?"

ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saɪɾ əz ɛɡwin faɪnəli ɝaɪvd, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hɔl ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð sɪlviænə. əz juʒəwəl, ðə sɑmbɝ ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkən lɝk bɪhaɪn laɪk ə dɪstənt ʃædoʊ. ʌnəknɑlədʒ baɪ ɛɡwin, nɑt bɑndəɾ əz əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, jɛt nɑt kæs fɹəm ðə taʊɝ iðɝ.

She took a deep breath, glancing to the side as Egwene finally arrived, walking toward the Hall in conversation with Silviana. As usual, the somber Gawyn Trakand lurked behind like a distant shadow. Unacknowledged by Egwene, not bonded as her Warder, yet not cast from the Tower either.

hid spɛn ðə naɪts sɪns ðə ɹiunəfəkeɪʃən ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz dɔɹz, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪɾ æŋɡɝd hɝ.

He'd spent the nights since the reunification guarding Egwene's doors, despite the fact that it angered her.

əz ɛɡwin nɪɹd ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə hɔl, sɪstɝz stɛp bæk ən meɪd weɪ, səm ɹɪlʌktənli, ʌðɝz ɹɛvɝənli. ʃid bɹɔt ðə taʊɝ tə ɪts niz fɹəm ði ɪnsaɪd, waɪl biɪŋ biɾən ɛvɹi deɪ ən daʊst wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ fɔkɹut ʃi kəd bɛɹli laɪɾ ə kændəl wɪð ðə paʊɝ. soʊ jʌŋ. jɛt wʌt wɑz eɪdʒ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ?

As Egwene neared the entrance to the Hall, sisters stepped back and made way, some reluctantly, others reverently. She'd brought the Tower to its knees from the inside, while being beaten every day and doused with so much forkroot she could barely light a candle with the Power. So young. Yet what was age to Aes Sedai?

"aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ aɪ wəd bi ðə wʌn ɪn ðɛɹ," sɪuən sɛd sɔfli, dʒʌs fəɹ bɹaɪn. "ðæɾ aɪ wəd ɹəsiv hɪm, ɡaɪd hɪm. aɪ wɑz ðə wʌn u wɑz tə bi sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðət tʃɛɹ."

"I always thought I would be the one in there," Siuan said softly, just for Bryne. "That I would receive him, guide him. I was the one who was to be sitting in that chair."

bɹaɪnz ɡɹɪp taɪɾənd. "sɪuən, aɪ . . ."

Bryne's grip tightened. "Siuan, I . . ."

"oʊ, doʊn bi laɪk ðæt," ʃi ɡɹaʊld, lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "aɪ doʊn ɹəɡɹɛɾ ə θɪŋ."

"Oh, don't be like that," she growled, looking at him. "I don't regret a thing."

hi fɹaʊnd.

He frowned.

"ɪts fəɹ ðə bɛst," sɪuən sɛd, ðoʊ ɪt twɪstəɾ əɹ ɪnsaɪdz ɪn nɑts tə ədmɪɾ ɪt. "fɔɹ ɔl əɹ tɪɹəni ən fulɪʃnəs, ɪts ɡʊd ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə ɹimuv mi, kəz ðəɾ ɪz wʌt lɛɾ əs tə ɛɡwin. ʃɪl də bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ kəd hæv. ɪts hɑɹd tə swɑloʊ - aɪ dɪd wɛl əz æmɪɝlɪn, bʌɾ aɪ kʊdn də ðæt. lɛd baɪ pɹɛzəns ɪnstɛɾ ə fɔɹs, junaɪɾɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə dɪvaɪɾɪŋ. ən soʊ, aɪm ɡlæd ðəɾ ɛɡwin ɪz ɹəsivɪŋ hɪm."

"It's for the best," Siuan said, though it twisted her insides in knots to admit it. "For all her tyranny and foolishness, it is good that Elaida removed me, because that is what led us to Egwene. She'll do better than I could have. It's hard to swallow - I did well as Amyrlin, but I couldn't do that. Lead by presence instead of force, uniting instead of dividing. And so, I'm glad that Egwene is receiving him."

bɹaɪn smaɪld, ən i skwizd əɹ ʃoʊldɝ fɑnli.

Bryne smiled, and he squeezed her shoulder fondly.

"wʌt?" ʃi æskt.

"What?" she asked.

"aɪm pɹaʊɾ ə ju."

"I'm proud of you."

ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz. "bɑ. ðət sɛntəmɛntælɪɾi ʌv jʊɹz ɪz gɑnə dʒɹaʊn mi wʌn ə ðiz deɪz."

She rolled her eyes. "Bah. That sentimentality of yours is going to drown me one of these days."

"ju kæn haɪd jəɹ ɡʊdnəs fɹəm mi, sɪuən sɑntʃ. aɪ si jəɹ hɑɹt."

"You can't hide your goodness from me, Siuan Sanche. I see your heart."

"ju ɑɹ sətʃ ə bəfun."

"You are such a buffoon."

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs. jə bɹɔɾ əs hɪɹ, sɪuən. wʌtɛvɝ haɪts ðət ɡɝl klaɪmz tə, ʃɪl də ɪt kəz jə kɑɹv ðə stɛps fəɹ hɝ."

"Regardless. You brought us here, Siuan. Whatever heights that girl climbs to, she'll do it because you carved the steps for her."

"jɛs, ðən hændəd ðə tʃɪzəl tə ɪleɪɾə." sɪuən ɡlæns təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin, hu stʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ ɪndə ðə hɔl. ðə jʌŋ æmɪɝlɪn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ðə wɪmən ɡæðɝɾ aʊtsaɪd, ən nɑɾəd ɪn ɡɹiɾɪŋ tə sɪuən. meɪbi ivən ə lɪɾəl ɪn ɹɪspɛkt.

"Yes, then handed the chisel to Elaida." Siuan glanced toward Egwene, who stood inside the doorway into the Hall. The young Amyrlin glanced over the women gathered outside, and nodded in greeting to Siuan. Maybe even a little in respect.

"ʃiz wʌt wi nid naʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd, "bʌt jəɹ wʌt wi niɾəd ðɛn. jə dɪd wɛl, sɪuən.

"She's what we need now," Bryne said, "but you're what we needed then. You did well, Siuan.

ʃi noʊz ɪt, ən ðə taʊɝ noʊz ɪt."

She knows it, and the Tower knows it."

ðət fɛl vɛɹi ɡʊd tə hɪɹ. "wɛl. dɪd jə si hɪm wən jə keɪm ɪn?"

That felt very good to hear. "Well. Did you see him when you came in?"

"jɛs," bɹaɪn sɛd. "hiz stændɪŋ bɪloʊ, wɑtʃt oʊvɝ baɪ ət list ə hʌnʒɹəd wɔɹɾɝz ən twɛnti-sɪks sɪstɝz - tu fʊl sɝkəlz. əndaʊɾɪdli hiz ʃildɪd, bʌɾ ɔl twɛnti-sɪks wɪmən simd ɪn ə nɪɹ pænɪk. noʊbɑdi dɛɹz tʌtʃ ɪm əɹ baɪn hɪm."

"Yes," Bryne said. "He's standing below, watched over by at least a hundred Warders and twenty-six sisters - two full circles. Undoubtedly he's shielded, but all twenty-six women seemed in a near panic. Nobody dares touch him or bind him."

"soʊ lɔŋ əz hiz ʃildɪd, ɪt ʃʊdn mæɾɝ. dɪɾ i lʊk fɹaɪɾənd? hɔɾi? æŋɡɹi?"

"So long as he's shielded, it shouldn't matter. Did he look frightened? Haughty? Angry?"

"nʌn ə ðæt."

"None of that."

"wɛl, wʌɾ i lʊk laɪk, ðɛn?"

"Well, what did he look like, then?"

"ɑnəsli, sɪuən? hi lʊk laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Honestly, Siuan? He looked like an Aes Sedai."

sɪuən snæpt əɹ dʒɔ kloʊzd. wɑz i tɔntɪŋ əɹ əɡɛn? noʊ, ðə dʒɛnɝəl sim sɪɹiəs. bʌt wʌɾ i min?

Siuan snapped her jaw closed. Was he taunting her again? No, the general seemed serious. But what did he mean?

ɛɡwin ɛntɝd ðə hɔl, ən ðən ə waɪt-dʒɹɛs nɑvəs wɛn skʌɾəlɪŋ əweɪ, teɪl baɪ tu ʌv tʃʌbnz soʊlʒɝz. ɛɡwin hæd sɛn fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən. bɹaɪn ɹɪmeɪnd wɪð ɪz hæn ɑn sɪuənz ʃoʊldɝ, stændɪŋ dʒʌs bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. sɪuən fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə bi kɑm.

Egwene entered the Hall, and then a white-dressed novice went scuttling away, tailed by two of Chubain's soldiers. Egwene had sent for the Dragon. Bryne remained with his hand on Siuan's shoulder, standing just behind her in the hallway. Siuan forced herself to be calm.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi sɔ moʊʃən ət ði ɛn ə ðə hɔlweɪ. ɝaʊn hɝ, sɪstɝz bɪɡæn tə ɡloʊ əz ðeɪ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. sɪuən ɹɪzɪstɪd ðət mɑɹk ʌv ɪnsɪkjʊɹɪɾi.

Eventually, she saw motion at the end of the hallway. Around her, sisters began to glow as they embraced the Source. Siuan resisted that mark of insecurity.

sun ə pɹəsɛʃən əpɹoʊtʃt, wɔɹɾɝz wɔkɪŋ ɪn ə skwɛɹ ɝaʊn ə tɔl fɪɡjɝ ɪn ə wɔɹn bɹaʊn kloʊk, twɛnti-sɪks ɛɛs sədaɪ fɑloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ðə fɪɡjɝ ɪnsaɪd ɡloʊd tə hɝ aɪz. ʃi hæd ðə tælən ə siɪŋ tɑvɝən, ən ælθɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ðoʊz tə ɛvɝ lɪv.

Soon a procession approached, Warders walking in a square around a tall figure in a worn brown cloak, twenty-six Aes Sedai following behind. The figure inside glowed to her eyes. She had the Talent of seeing ta'veren, and al'Thor was one of the most powerful of those to ever live.

ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə ɡloʊ, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət ðə bɔɪ hæd bɪkʌm ə mæn. ɔl hɪns ə juθfəl sɔfnəs wɝ ɡɔn, ɹipleɪst wɪð hɑɹd laɪnz. hid lɔs ði ʌnkɑnʃəsli slʌmpt pɑstʃɝ ðət mɛni jʌŋ mɛn ədæptəd, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðə tɔl wʌnz. ɪnstɛɾ i ɛmbɹeɪst ɪz haɪɾ əz ə mæn ʃʊd, wɔkɪŋ wɪð kəmænd. sɪuən hæd sin fɔls dʒɹæɡənz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ taɪm əz æmɪɝlɪn. ɑd, haʊ mʌtʃ ðɪs mæn ʃəd lʊk laɪk ðɛm. ɪt wɑz -  ʃi fɹoʊz əz i mɛɾ əɹ aɪz. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪndɪfaɪnəbəl əbaʊt ðɛm, ə weɪt, ən eɪdʒ. əz ðoʊ ðə mæn bɪhaɪn əm wɑz siɪŋ θɹu ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə θaʊzən laɪvz kəmpaʊndəɾ ɪn wʌn. hɪz feɪs dɪd lʊk laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðoʊz aɪz, ət list, hæɾ eɪɡləsnəs.

She forced herself to ignore the glow, looking at al'Thor himself. It appeared that the boy had become a man. All hints of youthful softness were gone, replaced with hard lines. He'd lost the unconsciously slumped posture that many young men adapted, particularly the tall ones. Instead he embraced his height as a man should, walking with command. Siuan had seen false Dragons during her time as Amyrlin. Odd, how much this man should look like them. It was -  She froze as he met her eyes. There was something indefinable about them, a weight, an age. As though the man behind them was seeing through the light of a thousand lives compounded in one. His face did look like that of an Aes Sedai. Those eyes, at least, had agelessness.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹeɪzd ɪz ɹaɪt hænd - hɪz lɛft ɑɹm wɑz foʊldəd bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk - ən hɔltəd ðə pɹəsɛʃən. "ɪf jə pliz," hi sɛd tə ðə wɔɹɾɝz, stɛpɪŋ θɹu ðɛm.

The Dragon Reborn raised his right hand - his left arm was folded behind his back - and halted the procession. "If you please," he said to the Warders, stepping through them.

ðə wɔɹɾɝz, ʃɑkt, lɛɾ ɪm pæs; ðə dʒɹæɡənz sɑf vɔɪs meɪɾ əm stɛp əweɪ. ðeɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ. ælθɹ wɔkt ʌp tə sɪuən, ən ʃi stil hɝsɛlf.

The Warders, shocked, let him pass; the Dragon's soft voice made them step away. They should have known better. Al'Thor walked up to Siuan, and she steeled herself.

hi wɑz ənɑɹmd ən ʃildɪd. hi kʊdn hɑɹm hɝ. stɪl, bɹaɪn stɛpt ʌp tə hɝ saɪɾ ən loʊɝɾ ɪz hæn tə hɪz sɔɹd.

He was unarmed and shielded. He couldn't harm her. Still, Bryne stepped up to her side and lowered his hand to his sword.

"pis, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn," ælθɹ sɛd. "aɪ wɪl də noʊ hɑɹm. juv lɛɾ əɹ bɑn ju, aɪ əsum?

"Peace, Gareth Bryne," al'Thor said. "I will do no harm. You've let her bond you, I assume?

kjʊɹiəs. ɪleɪn wɪl bi ɪntʃɹəstəd tə hɪɹ ə ðæt. ən sɪuən sɑntʃ. juv tʃeɪnʒd sɪns wi læs mɛt."

Curious. Elayne will be interested to hear of that. And Siuan Sanche. You've changed since we last met."

"tʃeɪnʒ kʌmz tə ɔl ʌv əs əz ðə wil tɝnz."

"Change comes to all of us as the Wheel turns."

"æn ɛɛs sədaɪ ænsɝ fəɹ sɝɾən." ælθɹ smaɪld. ə ɹɪlækst, sɑf smaɪl. ðət sɝpɹaɪz hɝ. "aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf əl ɛvɝ ɡɹoʊ əkʌstəm tə ðoʊz. jə wʌns tʊk ən æɹoʊ fəɹ mi. dɪɾ aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ðæt?"

"An Aes Sedai answer for certain." Al'Thor smiled. A relaxed, soft smile. That surprised her. "I wonder if I will ever grow accustomed to those. You once took an arrow for me. Did I thank you for that?"

"aɪ dɪdn də ɪɾ ɪntɛnʃənəli, əz aɪ ɹikɔl," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"I didn't do it intentionally, as I recall," she said dryly.

"ju hæv maɪ θæŋks nʌnðəlɛs." hi tɝn təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. "wʌt kaɪndə æmɪɝlɪn ɪz ʃi?"

"You have my thanks nonetheless." He turned toward the door to the Hall of the Tower. "What kind of Amyrlin is she?"

waɪ æsk mi? hi kʊdnt noʊ ʌv ðə kloʊsnɪs bɪtwin sɪuən ən ɛɡwin. "ʃiz ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl wʌn," sɪuən sɛd. "wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst wiv hæd, fəɹ ɔl ðə fæk ðət ʃiz oʊnli hɛl ðə siɾ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm."

Why ask me? He couldn't know of the closeness between Siuan and Egwene. "She's an incredible one," Siuan said. "One of the greatest we've had, for all the fact that she's only held the Seat a short time."

hi smaɪld əɡɛn. "aɪ ʃʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd nʌθɪŋ lɛs. stʃɹeɪnʒ, bʌɾ aɪ fil ðət siɪŋ əɹ əɡɛn wɪl hɝt, ðoʊ ðəɾ ɪz wʌn waʊn ðəɾ əz wɛl ən tʃɹuli hild. aɪ kən stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə peɪn ʌv ɪt, aɪ səpoʊz."

He smiled again. "I should have expected nothing less. Strange, but I feel that seeing her again will hurt, though that is one wound that has well and truly healed. I can still remember the pain of it, I suppose."

laɪt, bʌt ðɪs mæn wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə mʌɾəl ə hɝ ɛkspɛkteɪʃənz! ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz ə pleɪs ðət ʃʊɾə ənnɝvd ɛni mæn u kəd tʃænəl, dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɹ nɑt. jɛɾ i dɪdn sim wɝiɾ ɪn ðə list.

Light, but this man was making a muddle of her expectations! The White Tower was a place that should have unnerved any man who could channel, Dragon Reborn or not. Yet he didn't seem worried in the least.

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt wɑz kʌɾ ɔf əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ pʊʃt θɹu ðə ɡɹup. tiɑnə?

She opened her mouth, but was cut off as an Aes Sedai pushed through the group. Tiana?

ðə wʊmən pʊl sʌmθɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ sliv ən pɹɑfɝɾ ɪt tə ɹænd. ə smɔl lɛɾɝ wɪð ə ɹɛd sil. "ðɪs ɪz fəɹ ju," ʃi sɛd. hɝ vɔɪs saʊndəd tɛns, ən əɹ fɪŋɡɝz tʃɹɛmbəld, ðoʊ ðə tʃɹɛmbəl wɑz soʊ feɪn ðət moʊst wʊɾə mɪst ɪt. sɪuən hæd lɝn tə lʊk fəɹ saɪnz ʌv ɪmoʊʃən ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, haʊɛvɝ.

The woman pulled something out of her sleeve and proffered it to Rand. A small letter with a red seal. "This is for you," she said. Her voice sounded tense, and her fingers trembled, though the tremble was so faint that most would have missed it. Siuan had learned to look for signs of emotion in Aes Sedai, however.

ælθɹ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ðən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ən tʊk ɪt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

Al'Thor raised an eyebrow, then reached over and took it. "What is it?"

"aɪ pɹɑməs tə dɪlɪvɝ ɪt," tiɑnə sɛd. "aɪ wʊɾə sɛd noʊ, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt juɾ æktʃəli  kʌm tə ... aɪ min . . ." ʃi kʌt hɝsɛlf ɔf, kloʊzɪŋ əɹ maʊθ. ðən ʃi wɪθdʒɹu ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd.

"I promised to deliver it," Tiana said. "I would have said no, but I never thought you'd actually come to ... I mean . . ." She cut herself off, closing her mouth. Then she withdrew into the crowd.

ælθɹ slɪp ðə noʊɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət wɪθaʊt ɹiɾɪŋ ɪt. "du jəɹ bɛs tə kɑm ɛɡwin wən aɪm dʌn," hi sɛd tə sɪuən. ðən i tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən stʃɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪz ɡɑɹdz. ðeɪ heɪsən æftɝ hɪm, ðə wɔɹɾɝz lʊkɪŋ ʃipɪʃ, bʌt noʊbɑdi dɛɹd tʌtʃ ɪm əz i stʃɹoʊd bɪtwin ðə dɔɹz ən ɪndə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ.

Al'Thor slipped the note into his pocket without reading it. "Do your best to calm Egwene when I am done," he said to Siuan. Then he took a deep breath and strode forward, ignoring his guards. They hastened after him, the Warders looking sheepish, but nobody dared touch him as he strode between the doors and into the Hall of the Tower.

* * * hɛɹz bɹɪsəld ɑn ɛɡwinz ɑɹmz əz ɹænd keɪm ɪndə ðə ɹum, ʌnəkʌmpənid. ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊtsaɪd kɹaʊɾəd ɝaʊn ðə dɔɹweɪ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɡɔkɪŋ. sɪlviænə ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin.

* * * Hairs bristled on Egwene's arms as Rand came into the room, unaccompanied. Aes Sedai outside crowded around the doorway, trying to look as if they were not gawking. Silviana glanced at Egwene.

ʃəd ðɪs miɾɪŋ bi sil tə ðə hɔl?

Should this meeting be Sealed to the Hall?

noʊ, ɛɡwin θɔt.. ðeɪ nid tə si mi kənfɹʌn hɪm. laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn fil ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðɪs.

No, Egwene thought.. They need to see me confront him. Light, but I don't feel ready for this.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɛlpɪŋ ɪt. ʃi stil hɝsɛlf, ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ hɛd ðə seɪm wɝdz ʃid bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ɹænd ælθɹ, fɹɛn ə hɝ tʃaɪldhʊd, ðə mæn ʃiɾ əsum ðət ʃid wʌn deɪ mɛɹi. ɹænd ælθɹ ʃi kəd bi liniənt wɪð, bʌt linjənsi hɪɹ kəd bɹɪŋ əbaʊt ði ɛn ə ðə wɝld.

There was no helping it. She steeled herself, repeating in her head the same words she'd been going over all morning. This was not Rand al'Thor, friend of her childhood, the man she'd assumed that she'd one day marry. Rand al'Thor she could be lenient with, but leniency here could bring about the end of the world.

noʊ. ðɪs mæn wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs mæn ɛvɝ tə dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ. tɔl, mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt ðən ʃi ɛvɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪm biɪŋ. hi wɔɹ sɪmpəl kloʊðɪŋ.

No. This man was the Dragon Reborn. The most dangerous man ever to draw breath. Tall, much more confident than she ever remembered him being. He wore simple clothing.

hi wɔk dɝɛkli ɪndə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə hɔl, hɪz wɔɹɾɝ ɡɑɹdz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. hi stɑpt ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə fleɪm ɑn ðə flɔɹ, sɝaʊndəd baɪ sɪɾɝz ɪn ðɛɹ sits.

He walked directly into the center of the Hall, his Warder guards remaining outside. He stopped in the center of the Flame on the floor, surrounded by Sitters in their seats.

"ɛɡwin," ɹænd sɛd, vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ. hi nɑɾəd tə hɝ, əz ɪf ɪn ɹɪspɛkt. "ju hæv dʌn jəɹ pɑɹt, aɪ si. ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl fɪts jə wɛl."

"Egwene," Rand said, voice echoing in the chamber. He nodded to her, as if in respect. "You have done your part, I see. The Amyrlin's stole fits you well."

fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd hɝɾ ə ɹænd ɹisənli, ʃi hæd nɑɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd sətʃ kɑm ɪn hɪm. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ðə kɑm ə ðə kɹɪmənəl u hæd faɪnəli ɡɪvən hɪmsɛlf ʌp.

From what she had heard of Rand recently, she had not anticipated such calm in him. Perhaps it was the calm of the criminal who had finally given himself up.

wɑz ðət haʊ ʃi θɔɾ ə hɪm? əz ə kɹɪmənəl? hi hæd dʌn æks ðət sɝɾənli sim kɹɪmənəl;

Was that how she thought of him? As a criminal? He had done acts that certainly seemed criminal;

hi hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd, hi hæd kɑŋkɝd. wən ʃid læst spɛn ɛni lɛŋθ ə taɪm wɪð ɹænd, ðeɪ hæd tʃɹævəl θɹu ði il weɪst. hi hæd bɪkʌm ə hɑɹd mæn dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz mʌnθs, ən ʃi sɔ ðət hɑɹdnəs ɪn ɪm stɪl. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, sʌmθɪŋ dipɝ.

he had destroyed, he had conquered. When she'd last spent any length of time with Rand, they had traveled through the Aiel Waste. He had become a hard man during those months, and she saw that hardness in him still. But there was something else, something deeper.

"wʌɾ əz hæpən tə ju?" ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf æskɪŋ əz ʃi lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

"What has happened to you?" she found herself asking as she leaned forward on the Amyrlin Seat.

"aɪ wɑz bɹoʊkən," ɹænd sɛd, hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. 'æn ðɛn, ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, aɪ wɑz ɹɪfɔɝdʒd. aɪ θɪŋk i ɔlmoʊs hæd mi, ɛɡwin. ɪt wɑz kædzueɪn u sɛt mi tə fɪksɪŋ ɪt, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd soʊ baɪ æksəɾənt.

"I was broken," Rand said, hands behind his back. 'And then, remarkably, I was reforged. I think he almost had me, Egwene. It was Cadsuane who set me to fixing it, though she did so by accident.

stɪl, aɪ ʃæl əv tə lɪft əɹ ɛɡzaɪl, aɪ səspɛkt."

Still, I shall have to lift her exile, I suspect."

hi spoʊk dɪfɹənli. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɔɹmæləɾi tə hɪz wɝdz ðət ʃi dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. ɪn ənʌðɝ mæn, ʃi wʊɾə əsumd ə kʌltʃɝd, ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd bækɡɹaʊnd. bʌt ɹænd dɪdn əv ðæt. kəd tuɾɝz əv tʃɹeɪn ɪm soʊ kwɪkli?

He spoke differently. There was a formality to his words that she didn't recognize. In another man, she would have assumed a cultured, educated background. But Rand didn't have that. Could tutors have trained him so quickly?

"waɪ hæv jə kʌm bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit?" ʃi æskt. "hæv jə kʌm tə meɪk ə pətɪʃən, əɹ əv jə kʌm tə sɝɛndɝ jɝsɛlf tə ðə waɪt taʊɝz ɡaɪɾəns?"

"Why have you come before the Amyrlin Seat?" she asked. "Have you come to make a petition, or have you come to surrender yourself to the White Tower's guidance?"

hi stʌɾid hɝ, hænz stɪl bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. dʒʌs bɪhaɪn hɪm, θɝtin sɪstɝz kwaɪətli faɪld ɪndə ðə hɔl, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ ɝaʊn əm əz ðeɪ meɪnteɪn ɪz ʃild.

He studied her, hands still behind his back. Just behind him, thirteen sisters quietly filed into the Hall, the glow of saidar around them as they maintained his shield.

ɹænd dɪdn sim tə kɛɹ əbaʊt ðæt. hi stʌɾid ðə ɹum, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə vɛɹiəs sɪɾɝz. hɪz aɪz lɪŋɡɝɾ ɑn ðə sits ə ɹɛdz, tu ʌv wɪtʃ wɝ ɛmpti. pɛvɑɹə ən dʒəvɪnʒɹə hædn jɛt ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðɛɹ ənnoʊn mɪʃən. oʊnli bɑɹɑsin - nuli tʃoʊzən tə ɹipleɪs dʌɑɹə - wɑz ɪn ətɛndəns.

Rand didn't seem to care about that. He studied the room, looking at the various Sitters. His eyes lingered on the seats of Reds, two of which were empty. Pevara and Javindhra hadn't yet returned from their unknown mission. Only Barasine - newly chosen to replace Duhara - was in attendance.

tə hɝ kɹɛɾət, ʃi mɛt ɹændz aɪz ivənli.

To her credit, she met Rand's eyes evenly.

"aɪv heɪɾəd jə bɪfɔɹ," ɹænd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ɛɡwin. "aɪv fɛlt ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz, ɪn ɹisən mʌnθs. ɪt simz ðət fɹəm ðə vɛɹi moʊmən mɔɪɹeɪn keɪm tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, aɪv bɪn stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə əvɔɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ stʃɹɪŋz ə kəntʃɹoʊl. ən jɛt, aɪ əlaʊɾ ʌðɝ stʃɹɪŋz - mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs stʃɹɪŋz - tə ɹæp ɝaʊn mi ənsin.

"I've hated you before," Rand said, turning back to Egwene. "I've felt a lot of emotions, in recent months. It seems that from the very moment Moiraine came to the Two Rivers, I've been struggling to avoid Aes Sedai strings of control. And yet, I allowed other strings - more dangerous strings - to wrap around me unseen.

"ɪɾ əkɝz tə mi ðəɾ aɪv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tu hɑɹd. aɪ wɝid ðəɾ ɪf aɪ lɪsən tə ju, jud kəntʃɹoʊl mi.

"It occurs to me that I've been trying too hard. I worried that if I listened to you, you'd control me.

ɪt wɑzn ə dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ ɪndɪpɛndəns ðət dʒɹoʊv mi, bʌɾ ə fɪɹ ʌv ɪɹɛləvəns. ə fɪɹ ðət ði æks aɪ əkɑmplɪʃt wəd bi jʊɹz, ən nɑt maɪ oʊn." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ ʃʊɾə wɪʃt fəɹ sətʃ ə kənvinjən sɛɾ ə bæks əpɑn wɪtʃ tə hip ðə bleɪm fəɹ maɪ kɹaɪmz."

It wasn't a desire for independence that drove me, but a fear of irrelevance. A fear that the acts I accomplished would be yours, and not my own." He hesitated. "I should have wished for such a convenient set of backs upon which to heap the blame for my crimes."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd kʌm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ ɪn aɪɾəl fəlɑsəfi? pɝhæps i hæd ɡɔn mæd. "ɹænd," ɛɡwin sɛd, sɔfənɪŋ əɹ toʊn. "aɪm gɑnə hæv səm sɪstɝz tɔk tə jə tə dɪsaɪɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛniθɪŋ . . . ɹɔŋ wɪð ju. pliz tʃɹaɪ tə ʌndɝstænd."

Egwene frowned. The Dragon Reborn had come to the White Tower to engage in idle philosophy? Perhaps he had gone mad. "Rand," Egwene said, softening her tone. "I'm going to have some sisters talk to you to decide if there is anything . . . wrong with you. Please try to understand."

wʌns ðeɪ nu mɔɹ əbaʊɾ ɪz steɪt, ðeɪ kəd dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də wɪð hɪm. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn dɪd nid fɹiɾəm tə də əz ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛɾ i wʊd, bʌt kəd ðeɪ sɪmpli lɛɾ ɪm ɹoʊm əweɪ, naʊ ðət ðeɪ hæd hɪm?

Once they knew more about his state, they could decide what to do with him. The Dragon Reborn did need freedom to do as the prophecies said he would, but could they simply let him roam away, now that they had him?

ɹænd smaɪld. "oʊ, aɪ də ʌndɝstænd, ɛɡwin. ən aɪm sɑɹi tə dɪnaɪ ju, bʌɾ aɪ hæv tu mʌtʃ tə du. pipəl stɑɹv kəz ə mi, ʌðɝz lɪv ɪn tɛɹɝ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ hæv dʌn. ə fɹɛn ɹaɪdz tə hɪz dɛθ wɪθaʊɾ ælaɪz. ðəɹ ɪz soʊ lɪɾəl taɪm tə də wʌɾ aɪ mʌst."

Rand smiled. "Oh, I do understand, Egwene. And I am sorry to deny you, but I have too much to do. People starve because of me, others live in terror of what I have done. A friend rides to his death without allies. There is so little time to do what I must."

"ɹænd," ɛɡwin sɛd, "wi hæv tə meɪk ʃʊɹ."

"Rand," Egwene said, "we have to make sure."

hi nɑɾəd, əz ɪf ɪn ʌndɝstændɪŋ. "ðɪs ɪz ðə pɑɹt wʌn ɹəɡɹɛt. aɪ dɪd nɑt wɪʃ tə kʌm ɪndə jəɹ sɛntɝ ə paʊɝ, wɪtʃ juv ətʃiv soʊ wɛl, ən dɪfaɪ ju. bʌɾ ɪt kænɑt bi hɛlpt. jə mʌs noʊ wʌt maɪ plænz ɑɹ soʊ ðət jə kən pɹipɛɹ.

He nodded, as if in understanding. "This is the part I regret. I did not wish to come into your center of power, which you have achieved so well, and defy you. But it cannot be helped. You must know what my plans are so that you can prepare.

"ðə læs taɪm aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə sil ðə bɔɹ, aɪ wɑz fɔɹs tə də ɪt wɪθaʊt ðə hɛlp ə ðə wɪmən. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt lɛd tə dɪzæstɝ, ðoʊ ðeɪ meɪ hæv bɪn waɪz tə dɪnaɪ mi ðɛɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ. wɛl, bleɪm mʌs bi spɹɛɾ ivənli, bʌɾ əl nɑt meɪk ðə seɪm mɪsteɪks ə sɛkən taɪm. aɪ bɪliv ðət seɪɾɪn ən seɪaɪdɑɹ mʌs boʊθ bi juzd. aɪ doʊn əv ði ænsɝz jɛt."

"The last time I tried to seal the Bore, I was forced to do it without the help of the women. That was part of what led to disaster, though they may have been wise to deny me their strength. Well, blame must be spread evenly, but I will not make the same mistakes a second time. I believe that saidin and saidar must both be used. I don't have the answers yet."

ɛɡwin lin fɔɹwɝd, stʌɾiɪŋ hɪm. ðəɹ dɪdn sim tə bi mædnəs ɪn ɪz aɪz. ʃi nu ðoʊz aɪz. ʃi nu ɹænd.

Egwene leaned forward, studying him. There didn't seem to be madness in his eyes. She knew those eyes. She knew Rand.

laɪt, ʃi θɔt. aɪm ɹɔŋ. aɪ kæn θɪŋk ə hɪm oʊnli əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. aɪm hɪɹ fəɹ ə ɹizən.

Light, she thought. I'm wrong. I can't think of him only as the Dragon Reborn. I'm here for a reason.

hiz hɪɹ fəɹ ə ɹizən. tə mi, hi mʌs bi ɹænd. kəz ɹænd kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd, waɪl ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn mʌs bi fɪɹd.

He's here for a reason. To me, he must be Rand. Because Rand can be trusted, while the Dragon Reborn must be feared.

"wɪtʃ ɑɹ ju?" ʃi wɪspɝɾ ʌnkɑnʃəsli.

"Which are you?" she whispered unconsciously.

hi hɝd. "aɪ æm boʊθ, ɛɡwin. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɪm. luz θɝɪn. aɪ kən si hɪz ɪntaɪɝ laɪf, ɛvɹi dɛspɹɪt moʊmənt. aɪ si ɪt laɪk ə dʒɹim, bʌɾ ə klɪɹ dʒɹim. maɪ oʊn dʒɹim. ɪts pɑɹɾ ə mi."

He heard. "I am both, Egwene. I remember him. Lews Therin. I can see his entire life, every desperate moment. I see it like a dream, but a clear dream. My own dream. It's part of me."

ðə wɝdz wɝ ðoʊz ʌv ə mædmæn, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ spoʊkən ivənli. ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm, ən ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə juθ ðəɾ i hæd bɪn. ði ɝnɪs jʌŋ mæn. nɑt sɑləm laɪk pɛɹɪn, bʌt nɑt waɪld laɪk mæt. sɑləd, stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. ðə taɪp ə mæn jə kəd tʃɹʌst wɪð ɛniθɪŋ.

The words were those of a madman, but they were spoken evenly. She looked at him, and remembered the youth that he had been. The earnest young man. Not solemn like Perrin, but not wild like Mat. Solid, straightforward. The type of man you could trust with anything.

ivən ðə feɪɾ ə ðə wɝld.

Even the fate of the world.

"ɪn wʌn mʌnθs taɪm," ɹænd sɛd, "aɪm gɑnə tʃɹævəl tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ən bɹeɪk ðə læst ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. aɪ wɑn jəɹ hɛlp."

"In one month's time," Rand said, "I'm going to travel to Shayol Ghul and break the last remaining seals on the Dark One's prison. I want your help."

bɹeɪk ðə silz? ʃi sɔ ði ɪmədʒ fɹəm əɹ dʒɹim, ɹænd hækɪŋ ət ðə ɹoʊps ðət baʊn ðə kɹɪstəlaɪn ɡloʊb. "ɹænd, noʊ," ʃi sɛd.

Break the seals? She saw the image from her dream, Rand hacking at the ropes that bound the crystalline globe. "Rand, no," she said.

"aɪm gɑnə nid ju, ɔl ə ju," hi kəntɪnjud. "aɪ hoʊp tə ðə laɪt ðət ðɪs taɪm, jəl ɡɪmi jəɹ səpɔɹt. aɪ wɑn jə tə mit wɪð mi ɑn ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ən ðən . . . wɛl, ðən wɪl dɪskʌs maɪ tɝmz."

"I'm going to need you, all of you," he continued. "I hope to the Light that this time, you will give me your support. I want you to meet with me on the day before I go to Shayol Ghul. And then . . . well, then we will discuss my terms."

"jɔɹ tɝmz?" ɛɡwin dɪmændəd.

"Your terms?" Egwene demanded.

"ju wɪl si," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əz ɪf tə liv.

"You will see," he said, turning as if to leave.

"ɹæn ælθɹ!" ʃi sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "ju wɪl nɑt tɝn jəɹ bæk ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit!"

"Rand al'Thor!" she said, rising. "You will not turn your back on the Amyrlin Seat!"

hi fɹoʊz, ðən tɝn bæk təwɔɹd hɝ.

He froze, then turned back toward her.

"ju kæn bɹeɪk ðə silz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðæt wəd ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn fɹi."

"You can't break the seals," Egwene said. "That would risk letting the Dark One free."

"ə ɹɪsk wi mʌs teɪk. klɪɹ əweɪ ðə ɹʌbəl. ðə bɔɹ mʌs bi oʊpən fʊli əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ɪt kən bi sild."

"A risk we must take. Clear away the rubble. The Bore must be opened fully again before it can be sealed."

"wi mʌs tɔk əbaʊt ðɪs," ʃi sɛd. "plæn."

"We must talk about this," she said. "Plan."

"ðæɾ ɪz waɪ aɪ keɪm tə ju. tə lɛt jə plæn."

"That is why I came to you. To let you plan."

hi simd əmjuzd. laɪt! ʃi sæt bæk daʊn, æŋɡɹi. ðət bʊlhɛd-ɛdnəs ə hɪz wɑz dʒʌs laɪk ðəɾ ə hɪz fɑðɝ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz wi mʌst spik ʌv, ɹænd. nɑt dʒʌs ðɪs, bʌɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz - ðə sɪstɝz jəɹ mɛn əv bɑndəd nɑt ðə list əmʌŋ ðɛm."

He seemed amused. Light! She sat back down, angry. That bullhead-edness of his was just like that of his father. "There are things we must speak of, Rand. Not just this, but other things - the sisters your men have bonded not the least among them."

"wi kən spik ə ðət wən wi nɛks mit."

"We can speak of that when we next meet."

ʃi fɹaʊn ət hɪm.

She frowned at him.

"æn soʊ hɪɹ wi kʌm tə ɪt," ɹænd sɛd. hi baʊd tə hɝ - ə ʃæloʊ baʊ, ɔlmoʊs mɔɹ ə tɪp ə ðə hɛd. "ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz, fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, meɪ aɪ hæv jəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə wɪðdʒɹɔ?"

"And so here we come to it," Rand said. He bowed to her - a shallow bow, almost more a tip of the head. "Egwene al'Vere, Watcher of the Seals, Flame of Tar Valon, may I have your permission to withdraw?"

hi æskt ɪt soʊ pəlaɪtli. ʃi kʊdn tɛl ɪf i wɑz mɑkɪŋ əɹ əɹ nɑt. ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. doʊn meɪk mi də ɛniθɪŋ aɪ wəd ɹəɡɹɛt, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən sim tə seɪ.

He asked it so politely. She couldn't tell if he was mocking her or not. She met his eyes. Don't make me do anything I would regret, his expression seemed to say.

kəd ʃi ɹɪli kɑnfaɪn ɪm hɪɹ? æftɝ wʌt ʃid sɛd tə ɪleɪɾə əbaʊɾ ɪm niɾɪŋ tə bi fɹi?

Could she really confine him here? After what she'd said to Elaida about him needing to be free?

"aɪ wɪl nɑt lɛt jə bɹeɪk ðə silz," ʃi sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz mædnəs."

"I will not let you break the seals," she said. "That is madness."

"ðɛn mit wɪð mi ət ðə pleɪs noʊn əz ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ, dʒʌs tə ðə nɔɹθ. wɪl tɔk bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. fəɹ naʊ, aɪ də nɑt wɑnə dɪfaɪ ju, ɛɡwin. bʌɾ aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ."

"Then meet with me at the place known as the Field of Merrilor, just to the north. We will talk before I go to Shayol Ghul. For now, I do not want to defy you, Egwene. But I must go."

niðɝ ə ðɛm lʊkt əweɪ. ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə ɹum sim nɑt tə bɹið. ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz stɪl ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛɡwin tə hɪɹ ðə feɪn bɹiz meɪkɪŋ ðə ɹoʊz wɪndoʊ ɡɹoʊn ɪn ɪts lɛd.

Neither of them looked away. The others in the room seemed not to breathe. The chamber was still enough for Egwene to hear the faint breeze making the rose window groan in its lead.

"vɛɹi wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ɛndəd, ɹænd."

"Very well," Egwene said. "But this is not ended, Rand."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ noʊ ɛndɪŋz, ɛɡwin," hi ɹɪplaɪd, ðən nɑɾəd tə hɝ ən tɝn tə wɔk fɹəm ðə hɔl.

"There are no endings, Egwene," he replied, then nodded to her and turned to walk from the Hall.

laɪt! hi wɑz mɪsɪŋ ɪz lɛf hænd! haʊ hæd ðət hæpənd?

Light! He was missing his left hand! How had that happened?

ðə sɪstɝz ən wɔɹɾɝz ɹɪlʌktənli pɑɹɾəd fəɹ hɪm. ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ hɛd, filɪŋ dɪzi.

The sisters and Warders reluctantly parted for him. Egwene raised a hand to her head, feeling dizzy.

"laɪt!" sɪlviænə sɛd. "haʊ kəd jə θɪŋk dʊɹɪŋ ðæt, mʌðɝ?"

"Light!" Silviana said. "How could you think during that, Mother?"

"wʌt?" ɛɡwin lʊkt əbaʊt ðə hɔl. mɛni ʌv ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ slʌmpɪŋ vɪzəbli ɪn ðɛɹ sits.

"What?" Egwene looked about the Hall. Many of the Sitters were slumping visibly in their seats.

"sʌmθɪŋ ɡɹɪp maɪ hɑɹt," bɑɹɑsin sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə hɝ bɹɛst, "skwizɪŋ ɪt taɪt. aɪ dɪdn dɛɹ spik."

"Something gripped my heart," Barasine said, raising a hand to her breast, "squeezing it tight. I didn't dare speak."

"aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə spik," jukɪɝi sɛd. "maɪ maʊθ wʊdn muv."

"I tried to speak," Yukiri said. "My mouth wouldn't move."

"tɑvɝən" sɹɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ən ɪfɛkt əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ðət ... aɪ fɛl ðəɾ ɪt wəd kɹʌʃ mi fɹəm ði ɪnsaɪd."

"Ta'veren" Saerin said. "But an effect as strong as that ... I felt that it would crush me from the inside."

"haʊ dɪd jə ɹɪzɪst ɪt, mʌðɝ?" sɪlviænə æskt.

"How did you resist it, Mother?" Silviana asked.

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. ʃi hædn fɛl ðət weɪ. pɝhæps kəz ʃi θɔɾ ə hɪm əz ɹænd. "wi nid tə dɪskʌs ɪz wɝdz. ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ wɪl ɹikənvin ɪn wʌn aʊɝz taɪm fəɹ dɪskʌʃən." ðət kɑnvɝseɪʃən wəd bi sil tə ðə hɔl. "æn sʌmwʌn fɑloʊ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i ɹɪli livz."

Egwene frowned. She hadn't felt that way. Perhaps because she thought of him as Rand. "We need to discuss his words. The Hall of the Tower will reconvene in one hour's time for discussion." That conversation would be Sealed to the Hall. "And someone follow to make sure he really leaves."

"ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ɪz duɪŋ soʊ," tʃʌbn sɛd fɹəm aʊtsaɪd.

"Gareth Bryne is doing so," Chubain said from outside.

ðə sɪɾɝz pʊl ðɛmsɛlvz tə ðɛɹ fit, ʃeɪkən. sɪlviænə lin daʊn. "jɔɹ ɹaɪt, mʌðɝ.

The Sitters pulled themselves to their feet, shaken. Silviana leaned down. "You're right, Mother.

hi kæn bi əlaʊd tə bɹeɪk ðə silz. bʌt wʌɾ ɑɹ wi tə du? ɪf jə woʊn hoʊld ɪm kæptɪv . . ."

He can't be allowed to break the seals. But what are we to do? If you won't hold him captive . . ."

"aɪ daʊt wi cʊɾə hɛl hɪm," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm. aɪ... aɪ hæd ðə sɛns i cʊɾə bɹoʊkən ðət ʃild wɪθaʊɾ ə stʃɹʌɡəl."

"I doubt we could have held him," Egwene said. "There's something about him. I... I had the sense he could have broken that shield without a struggle."

"ðɛn haʊ? haʊ də wi stɑp hɪm?"

"Then how? How do we stop him?"

"wi niɾ ælaɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd. ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "hi maɪt bi pɝsweɪɾəd baɪ pipəl ðəɾ i tʃɹʌsts." əɹ i maɪt bi fɔɹs tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz maɪn ɪf kənfɹʌntəd baɪ ə lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf ɡɹup junaɪɾəd tə stɑp hɪm.

"We need allies," Egwene said. She took a deep breath. "He might be persuaded by people that he trusts." Or he might be forced to change his mind if confronted by a large enough group united to stop him.

ɪt wɑz naʊ mɔɹ vaɪɾəl ðət ʃi spik wɪð ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv.

It was now more vital that she speak with Elayne and Nynaeve.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹ


CHAPTER 4

ðə pæɾɝn ɡɹoʊnz


The Pattern Groans

wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" pɛɹɪn æskt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə ʃɑɹp sɛn ə ɹɑɾɪŋ mit. hi kʊdn si ɛni kɔɹpsəz, bʌt baɪ hɪz noʊz, ðə ɡɹaʊnd ʃəd bi lɪɾɝd wɪð ðɛm.

What is it?" Perrin asked, trying to ignore the sharp scent of rotting meat. He couldn't see any corpses, but by his nose, the ground should be littered with them.

hi stʊd wɪð ən ədvæns ɡɹup ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd, lʊkɪŋ nɔɹθwɝɾ əkɹɔs ə ɹoʊlɪŋ pleɪn wɪð fju tʃɹiz. ðə ɡɹæs wɑz bɹaʊn ən jɛloʊ, əz ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, bʌɾ ɪt ɡɹu dɑɹkɝ fɑɹðɝ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd, əz ɪf ɪnfɛktəd wɪð səm dɪziz.

He stood with an advance group at the side of the Jehannah Road, looking northward across a rolling plain with few trees. The grass was brown and yellow, as in other places, but it grew darker farther away from the road, as if infected with some disease.

"aɪv sin ðɪs bɪfɔɹ," siɑnɪd sɛd. ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv, peɪl-skɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ stupt ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹoʊd, tɝnɪŋ ðə lif ʌv ə smɔl wiɾ oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi wɔɹ ɡɹin wʊl, faɪn bʌɾ ənɔɹnəmɛntɪd, hɝ oʊnli dʒuəlɹi hɝ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ.

"I've seen this before," Seonid said. The diminutive, pale-skinned Aes Sedai stooped at the edge of the road, turning the leaf of a small weed over in her fingers. She wore green wool, fine but unornamented, her only jewelry her Great Serpent ring.

θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəl sɔfli əbʌv. sɪks waɪz wʌnz stʊd bɪhaɪn siɑnɪd, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, feɪsəz ənɹiɾəbəl. pɛɹɪn hædn kənsɪɾɝd tɛlɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz - əɹ ðɛɹ tu ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɹɛntəsɪz - tə steɪ bɪhaɪnd. hi wɑz pɹɑbli lʌki ðeɪ lɛɾ ɪm əkʌmpəni ðɛm.

Thunder rumbled softly above. Six Wise Ones stood behind Seonid, arms folded, faces unreadable. Perrin hadn't considered telling the Wise Ones - or their two Aes Sedai apprentices - to stay behind. He was probably lucky they let him accompany them.

"jɛs," nəvɛɝɪn sɛd, bɹeɪslɪts klæɾɝɪŋ əz ʃi nɛlt ən tʊk ðə lif fɹəm siɑnɪd. "aɪ vɪzəɾəd ðə blaɪt wʌns əz ə ɡɝl; maɪ fɑðɝ fɛlt ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ mi tə si. ðɪs lʊks laɪk wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ðɛɹ."

"Yes," Nevarin said, bracelets clattering as she knelt and took the leaf from Seonid. "I visited the Blight once as a girl; my father felt it important for me to see. This looks like what I saw there."

pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn tə ðə blaɪɾ oʊnli wʌns, bʌt ðə lʊk ə ðoʊz dɑɹk spɛks wɑz ɪndid dɪstɪŋktɪv.

Perrin had been to the Blight only once, but the look of those dark specks was indeed distinctive.

ə ɹɛdʒeɪ flʌɾɝd daʊn tə wʌn ə ðə dɪstən tʃɹiz ən bɪɡæn pɪkɪŋ ət bɹæntʃəz ən livz, bʌt faʊnd nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɪntʃɹəst ən tʊk wɪŋ əɡɛn.

A redjay fluttered down to one of the distant trees and began picking at branches and leaves, but found nothing of interest and took wing again.

ðə dɪstɝbɪŋ θɪŋ wɑz, ðə plæns hɪɹ sim bɛɾɝ ðən mɛni ðeɪd pæst əlɔŋ ðə weɪ.

The disturbing thing was, the plants here seemed better than many they'd passed along the way.

kʌvɝd wɪð spɑts, bʌɾ əlaɪv, ivən θɹaɪvɪŋ.

Covered with spots, but alive, even thriving.

laɪt, pɛɹɪn θɔt, teɪkɪŋ ðə lif əz nəvɛɝɪn hændəɾ ɪt tə hɪm. ɪt smɛld ə dəkeɪ. wʌt kaɪndə wɝld ɪz ɪt wɛɹ ðə blaɪɾ ɪz ðə ɡʊɾ ɔltɝnəɾɪv?

Light, Perrin thought, taking the leaf as Nevarin handed it to him. It smelled of decay. What kind of world is it where the Blight is the good alternative?

"mɔɹi sɝkəl ði ɪntaɪɝ pætʃ," nəvɛɝɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə meɪɾən stændɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ. "ɪt ɡɹoʊz dɑɹkɝ nɪɹ ðə sɛntɝ. ʃi kəd nɑt si wʌt wɑz ðɛɹ."

"Mori circled the entire patch," Nevarin said, nodding to a Maiden standing nearby. "It grows darker near the center. She could not see what was there."

pɛɹɪn nʌdʒ steɪɝ daʊn ɔf ðə ɹoʊd. feɪl fɑloʊd; ʃi dɪdn smɛl ðə lis bɪɾ əfɹeɪd, ðoʊ pɛɹɪnz tu ɹɪvɝz ɑɹmmɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Perrin nudged Stayer down off the road. Faile followed; she didn't smell the least bit afraid, though Perrin's Two Rivers armsmen hesitated.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn?" wɪl kɔld.

"Lord Perrin?" Wil called.

"ɪts pɹɑbli nɑt deɪnʒɝəs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ænəməlz stɪl muv ɪn ən aʊɾ ʌv ɪt." ðə blaɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs kəz ʌv wʌt lɪv ðɛɹ. ən ɪf ðoʊz bists hæd sʌmhaʊ kʌm saʊθwɝd, ðeɪ niɾəd tə noʊ. ði il stʃɹoʊɾ æftɝ ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ə kɑmɛnt. ən sɪns feɪl hæd dʒɔɪn hɪm, bɹəleɪn hæd tə əz wɛl, ənʊɹə ən ɡælɛn tʃɹeɪlɪŋ hɝ. blɛsədli, æliændɝ hæɾ əɡɹid tə ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd, ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə kæmp ən ɹɛfjudʒiz waɪl pɛɹɪn wɑz əweɪ.

"It's probably not dangerous," Perrin said. "Animals still move in and out of it." The Blight was dangerous because of what lived there. And if those beasts had somehow come southward, they needed to know. The Aiel strode after him without a comment. And since Faile had joined him, Berelain had to as well, Annoura and Gallenne trailing her. Blessedly, Alliandre had agreed to remain behind, in charge of the camp and refugees while Perrin was away.

ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi skɪɾɪʃ, ən ðə sɝaʊndɪŋz dɪdn hɛlp ðɛɹ mudz ɛni. pɛɹɪn bɹið θɹu hɪz maʊθ tə dæmpən ðə stɛntʃ ə ɹɑɾ ən dɛθ. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz wɛt hɪɹ tu - ɪf oʊnli ðoʊz klaʊdz wəd pæs soʊ ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt səm ɡʊd sʌnlaɪt tə dʒɹaɪ ðə sɔɪl - ən ðə hɔɹsəz'

The horses were already skittish, and the surroundings didn't help their moods any. Perrin breathed through his mouth to dampen the stench of rot and death. The ground was wet here too - if only those clouds would pass so they could get some good sunlight to dry the soil - and the horses'

fʊɾɪŋ wɑz tʃɹɛtʃɝəs, soʊ ðeɪ tʊk ðɛɹ taɪm. moʊst ə ðə mɛdoʊ wɑz kʌvɝɾ ɪn ɡɹæs, kloʊvɝ ən smɔl widz, ən ðə fɑɹðɝ ðeɪ ɹoʊd, ðə mɔɹ pɝveɪsɪv ðə dɑɹk spɑts bɪkeɪm. wɪðɪn mɪnəts, mɛni ʌv ðə plæns wɝ mɔɹ bɹaʊn ðən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɹin əɹ jɛloʊ.

footing was treacherous, so they took their time. Most of the meadow was covered in grass, clover and small weeds, and the farther they rode, the more pervasive the dark spots became. Within minutes, many of the plants were more brown than they were green or yellow.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ keɪm tə ə smɔl deɪl nɛsəld əmɪd θɹi hɪlsaɪdz. pɛɹɪn pʊl steɪɝ tə ə hɔlt;

Eventually they came to a small dale nestled amid three hillsides. Perrin pulled Stayer to a halt;

ði ʌðɝz bʌntʃt ʌp ɝaʊn hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ vɪlədʒ hɪɹ. ðə bɪldɪŋz wɝ hʌts bɪl fɹəm ən ɑd taɪp ʌv wʊd, laɪk lɑɹdʒ ɹidz, ən ðə ɹufs wɝ θætʃ - bʌt θætʃ bɪl fɹəm ɪnɔɹməs livz, əz waɪɾ əz tu mænz pɑmz.

the others bunched up around him. There was a strange village here. The buildings were huts built from an odd type of wood, like large reeds, and the roofs were thatch - but thatch built from enormous leaves, as wide as two man's palms.
