ðəɹ wɝ noʊ plæns hɪɹ, oʊnli ə vɛɹi sændi sɔɪl. pɛɹɪn slɪd fɹi ʌv ðə sæɾəl ən stup daʊn tə fil ɪt, ɹʌbɪŋ ðə ɡɹɪɾi stʌf bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ smɛl kənfjuzd.

There were no plants here, only a very sandy soil. Perrin slid free of the saddle and stooped down to feel it, rubbing the gritty stuff between his fingers. He looked at the others. They smelled confused.

hi kɔʃəsli lɛd steɪɝ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə vɪlədʒ. ðə blaɪt wɑz ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ fɹəm ðɪs pɔɪnt, bʌt ðə vɪlədʒ ɪtsɛlf ʃoʊd noʊ tʌtʃ ʌv ɪt. meɪɾənz skæɾɝd fɔɹwɝd, veɪlz ɪn pleɪs, səlɪn ət ðɛɹ hɛd. ðeɪ dɪɾ ə kwɪk ɪnspɛkʃən ə ðə hʌts, saɪnɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð kwɪk dʒɛstʃɝz, ðən ɹɪtɝnd.

He cautiously led Stayer forward into the center of the village. The Blight was radiating from this point, but the village itself showed no touch of it. Maidens scattered forward, veils in place, Sulin at their head. They did a quick inspection of the huts, signing to one another with quick gestures, then returned.

"noʊbɑdi?" feɪl æskt.

"Nobody?" Faile asked.

"noʊ," səlɪn sɛd, kɔʃəsli loʊɝɪŋ əɹ veɪl. "ðɪs pleɪs ɪz dɪzɝɾɪd."

"No," Sulin said, cautiously lowering her veil. "This place is deserted."

"hu wəd bɪld ə vɪlədʒ laɪk ðɪs," pɛɹɪn æskt, "ɪn ɡildən ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz?"

"Who would build a village like this," Perrin asked, "in Ghealdan of all places?"

"ɪt wɑzn bɪl hɪɹ," mɑsʊɝi sɛd.

"It wasn't built here," Masuri said.

pɛɹɪn tɝn təwɔɹd ðə slɛndɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Perrin turned toward the slender Aes Sedai.

"ðɪs vɪlədʒ ɪz nɑt neɪɾɪv tə ðɪs ɛɹiə," mɑsʊɝi sɛd. "ðə wʊɾ ɪz ənlaɪk ɛniθɪŋ aɪv sin bɪfɔɹ."

"This village is not native to this area," Masuri said. "The wood is unlike anything I've seen before."

'ðə pæɾɝn ɡɹoʊnz," bɹəleɪn sɛd sɔfli. "ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ, ði ɑd dɛθs. ɪn sɪɾiz, ɹumz vænɪʃ ən fud spɔɪlz."

'The Pattern groans," Berelain said softly. "The dead walking, the odd deaths. In cities, rooms vanish and food spoils."

pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ɪz tʃɪn, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ə deɪ wən ɪz æks hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm. ɪf ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒəz wɝ vænɪʃɪŋ ən əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, ɪf ðə blaɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ə ɹɪfs wɛɹ ðə pæɾɝn wɑz fɹeɪɪŋ . . . laɪt! haʊ bæd wɝ θɪŋz bɪkʌmɪŋ?

Perrin scratched his chin, remembering a day when his axe had tried to kill him. If entire villages were vanishing and appearing in other places, if the Blight was growing out of rifts where the Pattern was fraying . . . Light! How bad were things becoming?

"bɝn ðə vɪlədʒ," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ. "juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ. skaʊɝ əz mɛni ʌv ðə teɪntɪd plæns əz jə kæn. meɪbi wi kən kip ɪt fɹəm spɹɛɾɪŋ. wɪl muv ði ɑɹmi tə ðət kæmp ən aʊɝ əweɪ, ən wɪl steɪ ðəɹ təmɑɹoʊ ɪf jə nid mɔɹ taɪm."

"Burn the village," he said, turning. "Use the One Power. Scour as many of the tainted plants as you can. Maybe we can keep it from spreading. We'll move the army to that camp an hour away, and will stay there tomorrow if you need more time."

fəɹ wʌns, niðɝ ðə waɪz wʌnz nɔɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ vɔɪst soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə snɪf ə kəmpleɪn ət ðə dɝɛkt ɔɹɾɝ.

For once, neither the Wise Ones nor the Aes Sedai voiced so much as a sniff of complaint at the direct order.

hʌnt wɪð ʌs, bɹʌðɝ.

Hunt with us, brother.

pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. hi veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝd sɪɾɪŋ dʒɹaʊsəli baɪ ðə dwɪndəlɪŋ laɪɾ ʌv ən oʊpən læmp, ə sɪŋɡəl fleɪm ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɑn ɪts tɪp, weɪɾɪŋ tə hɪɹ ə ɹipɔɹt fɹəm ðoʊz dilɪŋ wɪð ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ vɪlədʒ. hi hæd bɪn ɹiɾɪŋ ə kɑpi ʌv ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ ðət ɡɔl hæd faʊn əmʌŋ ðə sælvədʒ fɹəm meɪɾən.

Perrin found himself in the wolf dream. He vaguely remembered sitting drowsily by the dwindling light of an open lamp, a single flame shivering on its tip, waiting to hear a report from those dealing with the strange village. He had been reading a copy of The Travels of Jain Farstrider that Gaul had found among the salvage from Maiden.

naʊ pɛɹɪn leɪ ɑn ɪz bæk ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ fild wɪð ɡɹæs əz tɔl əz ə mænz weɪst. hi ɡeɪzd ʌp, ɡɹæs bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz tʃiks ən ɑɹmz əz ɪt ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ɪn ðə skaɪ, ðət seɪm stɔɹm bɹud, hɪɹ əz ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld. mɔɹ vaɪələn hɪɹ.

Now Perrin lay on his back in the middle of a large field with grass as tall as a man's waist. He gazed up, grass brushing his cheeks and arms as it shivered in the wind. In the sky, that same storm brewed, here as in the waking world. More violent here.

stɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪt - hɪz vɪʒən fɹeɪm baɪ ðə stɔks ə bɹaʊn ən ɡɹin ɡɹæs ən stɛmz ʌv waɪl mɪlət - hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə stɔɹm ɡɹoʊɪŋ kloʊsɝ. əz ɪf ɪt wɑz kɹɔlɪŋ daʊn aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ tə ɪnɡʌlf hɪm.

Staring up at it - his vision framed by the stalks of brown and green grass and stems of wild millet - he could almost feel the storm growing closer. As if it was crawling down out of the sky to engulf him.

jʌŋ bʊl! kʌm! kʌm hʌnt!

Young Bull! Come! Come hunt!

ðə vɔɪs wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ə wʊlf. pɛɹɪn baɪ ɪnstɪŋk nu ðət ʃi wɑz kɔld oʊk dænsɝ, neɪm fəɹ ðə weɪ ʃi hæd skæmpɝd bɪtwin sæplɪŋz əz ə wɛlp. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz, tu. wɪspɝɝ.

The voice was that of a wolf. Perrin by instinct knew that she was called Oak Dancer, named for the way she had scampered between saplings as a whelp. There were others, too. Whisperer.

mɔɹnɪŋɡlaɪt. spɑɹks, baʊnləs. ə ɡʊd dʌzən wʊlvz kɔl tə hɪm, səm lɪvɪŋ wʊlvz u slɛpt, ʌðɝz ðə spɪɹəts ʌv wʊlvz u hæd daɪd.

Morninglight. Sparks, boundless. A good dozen wolves called to him, some living wolves who slept, others the spirits of wolves who had died.

ðeɪ kɔl tə hɪm wɪð ə mɪkstʃɝ ə sɛns ən ɪmədʒəz ən saʊnz. ðə smɛl ʌv ə spɹɪŋ bʌk, pɑkɪŋ ði ɝθ wɪð ɪts lips. fɔlən livz kɹʌmbəlɪŋ bɪniθ ɹʌnɪŋ wʊlvz. ðə ɡɹaʊlz ə vɪktɝi, ðə θɹɪl ʌv ə pæk ɹʌnɪŋ təɡɛðɝ.

They called to him with a mixture of scents and images and sounds. The smell of a spring buck, pocking the earth with its leaps. Fallen leaves crumbling beneath running wolves. The growls of victory, the thrill of a pack running together.

ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz əweɪkən sʌmθɪŋ dip wɪðɪn hɪm, ðə wʊlf i tʃɹaɪd tə kip lɑkt əweɪ. bʌɾ ə wʊlf kəd nɑt bi lɑkt ʌp fəɹ lɔŋ. ɪt: iðɝ ɪskeɪpt əɹ ɪt daɪd; ɪt wəd nɑt stæn kæptɪvəɾi. hi lɔŋ tə lip tə hɪz fiɾ ən sɛn ɪz dʒɔɪəs æksɛptəns, luzɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə pæk. hi wɑz jʌŋ bʊl, ən i wɑz wɛlkəm hɪɹ.

The invitations awakened something deep within him, the wolf he tried to keep locked away. But a wolf could not be locked up for long. It: either escaped or it died; it would not stand captivity. He longed to leap to his feet and send his joyous acceptance, losing himself in the pack. He was Young Bull, and he was welcome here.

"noʊ!" pɛɹɪn sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ wɪl nɑt luz maɪsɛlf ɪn ju."

"No!" Perrin said, sitting up, holding his head. "I will not lose myself in you."

hɑpɝ sæɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹæs tə hɪz ɹaɪt. ðə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹeɪ wʊlf ɹəɡɑɹɾəd pɛɹɪn, ɡoʊldən aɪz ənblɪŋkɪŋ, ɹəflɛktɪŋ flæʃɪz ə laɪɾɪŋ fɹəm əbʌv. ðə ɡɹæs keɪm ʌp tə hɑpɝz nɛk.

Hopper sat in the grass to his right. The large gray wolf regarded Perrin, golden eyes unblinking, reflecting flashes of lighting from above. The grass came up to Hopper's neck.

pɛɹɪn loʊɝɾ ə hæn fɹəm ɪz hɛd. ði ɛɹ wɑz hɛvi, fʊl ə hjumɪɾəti, ən ɪt smɛld ə ɹeɪn.

Perrin lowered a hand from his head. The air was heavy, full of humidity, and it smelled of rain.

əbʌv ðə sɛn ə ðə wɛðɝ ən ðəɾ ə ðə dʒɹaɪ fild, hi kəd smɛl hɑpɝz peɪʃəns.

Above the scent of the weather and that of the dry field, he could smell Hopper's patience.

jə ɑɹ ɪnvaɪɾəd, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

You are invited, Young Bull, Hopper sent.

"aɪ kæn hʌnt wɪð ju," pɛɹɪn ɪkspleɪnd. "hɑpɝ, wi spoʊk ə ðɪs. aɪm luzɪŋ maɪsɛlf. wən aɪ ɡoʊ ɪndə bæɾəl, aɪ bɪkʌm ɛnɹeɪdʒd. laɪk ə wʊlf."

"I can't hunt with you," Perrin explained. "Hopper, we spoke of this. I'm losing myself. When I go into battle, I become enraged. Like a wolf."

laɪk ə wʊlf? hɑpɝ sɛnt. jʌŋ bʊl, jə ɑɹ ə wʊlf. ən ə mæn. kʌm hʌnt.

Like a wolf? Hopper sent. Young Bull, you are a wolf. And a man. Come hunt.

"aɪ toʊl jə aɪ kænt! əl nɑt lɛt ðɪs kənsum mi." hi θɔɾ ʌv ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð ɡoʊldən aɪz, lɑkt ɪn ə keɪdʒ, ɔl hjumænɪɾi ɡɔn fɹəm hɪm. hɪz neɪm hæd bɪn noʊm - pɛɹɪn hæd sin ɪm ɪn ə vɪlədʒ kɔl dʒɹə.

"I told you I can't! I will not let this consume me." He thought of a young man with golden eyes, locked in a cage, all humanity gone from him. His name had been Noam - Perrin had seen him in a village called Jarra.

laɪt, pɛɹɪn θɔt. ðæts nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm hɪɹ. əɹ ət lis nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ɪz bɑɾi slʌmbɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld. dʒɹə wɑz ɪn ɡildən. ən ɑd koʊɪnsɪɾəns.

Light, Perrin thought. That's not far from here. Or at least not far from where his body slumbered in the real world. Jarra was in Ghealdan. An odd coincidence.

wɪð ə tɑ vɹən nɪɹbaɪ, ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz.

With a ta veren nearby, there are no coincidences.

hi fɹaʊnd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ən skænɪŋ ðə lændskeɪp. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊl pɛɹɪn ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ hjumən lɛft ɪnsaɪɾ ə noʊm. ðət wɑz wʌɾ əweɪɾəd ə wʊlfbɹəðɝ ɪf i lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi kəmplitli kənsum baɪ ðə wʊlf.

He frowned, rising and scanning the landscape. Moiraine had told Perrin there was nothing human left inside of Noam. That was what awaited a wolfbrother if he let himself be completely consumed by the wolf.

"aɪ mʌs lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɪs, əɹ aɪ mʌs bænɪʃ ðə wʊlf fɹəm mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ taɪm lɛft fəɹ kɑmpɹəmaɪz, hɑpɝ."

"I must learn to control this, or I must banish the wolf from me," Perrin said. "There is no time left for compromise, Hopper."

hɑpɝ smɛl dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. hi dɪdn laɪk wʌt hid kɔld ə hjumən tɛndənsi tə wɪʃ tə kəntʃɹoʊl θɪŋz.

Hopper smelled dissatisfied. He didn't like what he'd called a human tendency to wish to control things.

kʌm, hɑpɝ sɛnt, stændɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə ɡɹæs. hʌnt.

Come, Hopper sent, standing up in the grass. Hunt.

kʌm lɝn, hɑpɝ sɛnt, fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. ðə læs hʌn kʌmz.

Come learn, Hopper sent, frustrated. The Last Hunt comes.

hɑpɝz sɛndɪŋz ɪnkluɾəd ði ɪmədʒ ʌv ə jʌŋ pʌp meɪkɪŋ ɪz fɝs kɪl. ðəɾ ən ə wɝi fəɹ ðə fjutʃɝ - ə nɔɹməli ənwʊlflaɪk ətʃɹɪbjut, ðə læs hʌn bɹɔt tʃeɪnʒ.

Hopper's sendings included the image of a young pup making his first kill. That and a worry for the future - a normally unwolflike attribute, the Last Hunt brought change.

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɪn ə pɹiviəs vɪzət tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, pɛɹɪn hæd dɪmændəd ðət hɑpɝ tʃɹeɪn ɪm tə mæstɝ ðə pleɪs. vɛɹi ɪnəpɹoʊpɹiɪt fəɹ ə jʌŋ wʊlf - ə kaɪndə tʃælənʒ tə ði ɛldɝz sinjɔɹɪɾi  - bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə ɹɪspɑns. hɑpɝ hæd kʌm tə titʃ, bʌɾ i wəd də ɪɾ əz ə wʊlf tɔt.

Perrin hesitated. In a previous visit to the wolf dream, Perrin had demanded that Hopper train him to master the place. Very inappropriate for a young wolf - a kind of challenge to the elder's seniority  - but this was a response. Hopper had come to teach, but he would do it as a wolf taught.

"aɪm sɑɹi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɪl hʌnt wɪð jə - bʌɾ aɪ mʌs nɑt luz maɪsɛlf."

"I'm sorry," Perrin said. "I will hunt with you - but I must not lose myself."

ðiz θɪŋz jə θɪŋk, hɑpɝ sɛnt, dɪsplizd. haʊ kən jə θɪŋk sətʃ ɪmədʒəz ə nʌθɪŋ? ðə ɹɪspɑns wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ ɪmədʒəz ə blæŋknəs - ən ɛmpti skaɪ, ə dɛn wɪð noʊbɑdi ɪn ɪt, ə bæɹən fild. jə ɑɹ jʌŋ bʊl. jəl ɔlweɪz bi jʌŋ bʊl. haʊ kən jə luz jʌŋ bʊl? lʊk daʊn, ən jəl si hɪz pɔz bɪniθ. baɪt, ən ɪz tiθ wɪl kɪl. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ luzɪŋ ðɪs.

These things you think, Hopper sent, displeased. How can you think such images of nothing? The response was accompanied by images of blankness - an empty sky, a den with nobody in it, a barren field. You are Young Bull. You will always be Young Bull. How can you lose Young Bull? Look down, and you will see his paws beneath. Bite, and his teeth will kill. There is no losing this.

"ɪɾ ɪz ə θɪŋ ə hjumənz."

"It is a thing of humans."

ðə seɪm ɛmpti wɝdz oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

The same empty words over and over, Hopper sent.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, sʌkɪŋ ɪn ən ɹilisɪŋ ðə tu-wɛɾ ɛɹ. "vɛɹi wɛl," hi sɛd, hæmɝ ən naɪf əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænz. "lɛts ɡoʊ."

Perrin took a deep breath, sucking in and releasing the too-wet air. "Very well," he said, hammer and knife appearing in his hands. "Let's go."

jə hʌnt ɡeɪm wɪð jəɹ hʊvz? ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ə bʊl ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪts hɔɹnz ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lip ɑntu ðə bæk ʌv ə dɪɹ ən stɑmp ɪt tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

You hunt game with your hooves? An image of a bull ignoring its horns and trying to leap onto the back of a deer and stomp it to the ground.

"jɔɹ ɹaɪt." pɛɹɪn wɑz sʌɾənli hoʊldɪŋ ə ɡʊd tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊ. hi wɑzn əz ɡʊɾ ə ʃɑɾ əz dʒɑndɪn bæɹən əɹ ɹænd, bʌɾ i kəd hoʊld ɪz oʊn.

"You're right." Perrin was suddenly holding a good Two Rivers longbow. He wasn't as good a shot as Jondyn Barran or Rand, but he could hold his own.

hɑpɝ sɛn ə bʊl spɪɾɪŋ əɾ ə dɪɹ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, sɛndɪŋ bæk ə wʊlfs klɔz ʃuɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪts pɔz ən stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ə dɪɹ əɾ ə dɪstəns, bʌt ðɪs oʊnli sim tə əmjuz hɑpɝ fɝðɝ. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ənɔɪəns, pɛɹɪn hæd tə ədmɪt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə ɹæðɝ ɹɪdɪkjələs ɪmədʒ.

Hopper sent a bull spitting at a deer. Perrin growled, sending back a wolf's claws shooting from its paws and striking a deer at a distance, but this only seemed to amuse Hopper further. Despite his annoyance, Perrin had to admit that it was a rather ridiculous image.

ðə wʊlf sɛn ði ɪmədʒ tə ði ʌðɝz, kɑzɪŋ əm tə haʊl ɪn əmjuzmənt, ðoʊ moʊst ə ðɛm sim tə pɹəfɝ ðə bʊl dʒʌmpɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ɑn ðə dɪɹ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ hɑpɝ təwɔɹd ðə dɪstənt wʊdz, wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊlvz weɪɾəd.

The wolf sent the image to the others, causing them to howl in amusement, though most of them seemed to prefer the bull jumping up and down on the deer. Perrin growled, chasing after Hopper toward the distant woods, where the other wolves waited.

əz i ɹæn, ðə ɡɹæsəz sim tə ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ dɛns. ðeɪ hɛld ɪm bæk, laɪk snɑɹəl fɔɹəst ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ. hɑpɝ sun aʊtpeɪs hɪm.

As he ran, the grasses seemed to grow more dense. They held him back, like snarled forest undergrowth. Hopper soon outpaced him.

ɹʌn, jʌŋ bʊl!

Run, Young Bull!

aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ, pɛɹɪn sɛn bæk.

I'm trying, Perrin sent back.

nɑɾ əz juv bɪfɔɹ!

Not as you have before!

pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə pʊʃ ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə ɡɹæs. ðɪs stʃɹeɪnʒ pleɪs, ðɪs wʌndɝfəl wɝld wɛɹ wʊlvz ɹæn, kəd bi ɪntɑksɪkeɪɾɪŋ. ən deɪnʒɝəs. hɑpɝ hæd wɔɹn pɛɹɪn ə ðət mɔɹ ðən wʌns.

Perrin continued to push his way through the grass. This strange Place, this wonderful world where wolves ran, could be intoxicating. And dangerous. Hopper had warned Perrin of that more than once.

deɪnʒɝz fəɹ təmɑɹoʊ. ɪɡnɔɹ əm fəɹ naʊ, hɑpɝ sɛnt, ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ dɪstənt. wɝi ɪz fəɹ tu-lɛɡz.

Dangers for tomorrow. Ignore them for now, Hopper sent, growing more distant. Worry is for two-legs.

aɪ kæn ɪɡnɔɹ maɪ pɹɑbləmz! pɛɹɪn θɔt bæk.

I can't ignore my problems! Perrin thought back.

jɛt jə ɔfən du, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

Yet you often do, Hopper sent.

ɪt stʃɹʌk tʃɹu - mɔɹ tʃɹu, pɝhæps, ðən ðə wʊlf nu. pɛɹɪn bɝst ɪndə ə klɪɹɪŋ ən pʊl tə ə hɔlt. ðɛɹ, laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɝ ðə θɹi tʃʌŋks ə mɛɾəl hid fɔɹdʒd ɪn ɪz ɝliɝ dʒɹim. ðə lɑɹdʒ lʌmp ðə saɪz ə tu fɪsts, ðə flæɾənd ɹɑd, ðə θɪn ɹɛktæŋɡəl. ðə ɹɛktæŋɡəl ɡloʊd feɪnli jɛloʊ-ɹɛd, sɪŋɡɪŋ ðə ʃɔɹt ɡɹæs ɝaʊn ɪt.

It struck true - more true, perhaps, than the wolf knew. Perrin burst into a clearing and pulled to a halt. There, lying on the ground, were the three chunks of metal he'd forged in his earlier dream. The large lump the size of two fists, the flattened rod, the thin rectangle. The rectangle glowed faintly yellow-red, singeing the short grass around it.

ðə lʌmps vænɪʃt ɪmiɾiətli, ðoʊ ðə sɪmɝɪŋ ɹɛktæŋɡəl lɛft ə bɝn spɑt. pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə wʊlvz. əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv ðə tʃɹiz əhɛd, ə lɑɹdʒ hoʊl ə blæknəs oʊpən ʌp. hi kəd nɑt tɛl haʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz əweɪ, ən ɪt sim tə dɑməneɪɾ ɔl i kəd si waɪl biɪŋ dɪstən ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

The lumps vanished immediately, though the simmering rectangle left a burned spot. Perrin looked up, searching for the wolves. Ahead of him, in the sky above the trees ahead, a large hole of blackness opened up. He could not tell how far it was away, and it seemed to dominate all he could see while being distant at the same time.

mæt stʊd ðɛɹ. hi wɑz faɪɾɪŋ əɡɛns hɪmsɛlf, ə dʌzən dɪfɹən mɛn wɛɹɪŋ ɪz feɪs, ɔl dʒɹɛst ɪn dɪfɹən taɪps ə faɪn kloʊðɪŋ. mæt spʌn ɪz spɪɹ, ən nɛvɝ sɔ ðə ʃæɾoʊi fɪɡjɝ kɹipɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, bɛɹɪŋ ə blʌɾi naɪf.

Mat stood there. He was fighting against himself, a dozen different men wearing his face, all dressed in different types of fine clothing. Mat spun his spear, and never saw the shadowy figure creeping behind him, bearing a bloody knife.

"mæt!" pɛɹɪn kɹaɪd, bʌɾ i nu ɪt wɑz minɪŋləs. ðɪs θɪŋ i wɑz siɪŋ, ɪt wɑz səm kaɪndə dʒɹim əɹ vɪʒən ə ðə fjutʃɝ. ɪt hæd bɪn səm taɪm sɪns hid sin wʌn ə ðiz. hiɾ ɔlmoʊs bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd stɑp kʌmɪŋ.

"Mat!" Perrin cried, but he knew it was meaningless. This thing he was seeing, it was some kind of dream or vision of the future. It had been some time since he'd seen one of these. He'd almost begun to think they would stop coming.

hi tɝn əweɪ ən ənʌðɝ dɑɹknəs oʊpən ɪn ðə skaɪ. hi sɔ ʃip, sʌɾənli, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ə flɑk təwɔɹd ðə wʊdz. wʊlvz tʃeɪs ðɛm, ən ə tɛɹəbəl bist weɪɾəd ɪn ðə wʊdz, ənsin. hi wɑz ðɛɹ, ɪn ðət dʒɹim, hi sɛnst. bʌɾ u wɑz i tʃeɪsɪŋ, ən waɪ? sʌmθɪŋ lʊkt ɹɔŋ wɪð ðoʊz wʊlvz.

He turned away and another darkness opened in the sky. He saw sheep, suddenly, running in a flock toward the woods. Wolves chased them, and a terrible beast waited in the woods, unseen. He was there, in that dream, he sensed. But who was he chasing, and why? Something looked wrong with those wolves.

ə θɝd dɑɹknəs, tə ðə saɪd. feɪl, ɡɹeɪɾi, ɛlaɪəs, ɡɔl ... ɔl wɔk təwɔɹɾ ə klɪf, fɑloʊd baɪ θaʊzənz ʌv ʌðɝz.

A third darkness, to the side. Faile, Grady, Elyas, Gaul ... all walked toward a cliff, followed by thousands of others.

ðə vɪʒən kloʊzd. hɑpɝ sʌɾənli ʃɑt bæk θɹu ði ɛɹ, lændɪŋ bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn, skɪɾɪŋ tə ə stɑp. ðə wʊlf wʊdn əv sin ðə hoʊlz; ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ əpɪɹd tə hɪz aɪz. ɪnstɛd, hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə bɝn pætʃ wɪð dɪsdeɪn ən sɛn ði ɪmədʒ ə pɛɹɪn, ənkɛmpt ən blɪɹi-aɪd, hɪz bɪɹɾ ən hɛɹ əntʃɹɪmd ən ɪz kloʊðɪŋ dɪʃɛvəld. pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə taɪm; ɪt hæd bɪn dʊɹɪŋ ði ɝli deɪz ə feɪlz kæptɪvəɾi.

The vision closed. Hopper suddenly shot back through the air, landing beside Perrin, skidding to a stop. The wolf wouldn't have seen the holes; they had never appeared to his eyes. Instead, he regarded the burned patch with disdain and sent the image of Perrin, unkempt and bleary-eyed, his beard and hair untrimmed and his clothing disheveled. Perrin remembered the time; it had been during the early days of Faile's captivity.

hæɾ i ɹɪli lʊk ðət bæd? laɪt, bʌɾ i simd ɹæɡəd. ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə bɛɡɝ. əɹ . . . laɪk noʊm.

Had he really looked that bad? Light, but he seemed ragged. Almost like a beggar. Or . . . like Noam.

"stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənfjuz mi!" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ bɪkeɪm ðət weɪ kəz aɪ wɑz dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə faɪndɪŋ feɪl, nɑt kəz aɪ wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ ɪn tə ðə wʊlvz!"

"Stop trying to confuse me!" Perrin said. "I became that way because I was dedicated to finding Faile, not because I was giving in to the wolves!"

ðə nuəs pʌps ɔlweɪz bleɪm ði ɛldɝz ə ðə pæk. hɑpɝ baʊndəd θɹu ðə ɡɹæsəz əɡɛn.

The newest pups always blame the elders of the pack. Hopper bounded through the grasses again.

wʌd ðət min? ðə sɛns ən ɪmədʒəz kənfjuz hɪm. ɡɹoʊlɪŋ, pɛɹɪn tʃɑɹdʒ fɔɹwɝd, livɪŋ ðə klɪɹɪŋ ən ɹiɪntɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹæsəz. wʌns əɡɛn ðə stɔks ɹɪzɪstɪd hɪm. ɪt wɑz laɪk faɪɾɪŋ əɡɛnst ə kɝənt, hɑpɝ ʃɑɾ ɑn əhɛd.

What did that mean? The scents and images confused him. Growling, Perrin charged forward, leaving the clearing and reentering the grasses. Once again the stalks resisted him. It was like fighting against a current, Hopper shot on ahead.

"bɝn ju, weɪt fəɹ mi!" pɛɹɪn jɛld.

"Burn you, wait for me!" Perrin yelled.

ɪf wi weɪt, wi luz ðə pɹeɪ. ɹʌn, jʌŋ bʊl!

If we wait, we lose the prey. Run, Young Bull!

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. hɑpɝ wɑz ə spɛk ɪn ðə dɪstəns naʊ, ɔlmoʊs tə ðə tʃɹiz. pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə θɪŋk ɑn ðoʊz vɪʒənz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn taɪm. ɪf i lɔs hɑpɝ, hi nu ðəɾ i wəd nɑt si hɪm əɡɛn ðɪs naɪt. faɪn, hi θɔt wɪð ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən.

Perrin gritted his teeth. Hopper was a speck in the distance now, almost to the trees. Perrin wanted to think on those visions, but there wasn't time. If he lost Hopper, he knew that he would not see him again this night. Fine, he thought with resignation.

ðə læn lɝtʃt ɝaʊn hɪm, ɡɹæsəz spiɾɪŋ baɪ ɪn ə flæʃ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf pɛɹɪn hæd lɛpt ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ɪn wʌn stɛp. hi stɛpt əɡɛn, ʃuɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. hi lɛft ə feɪn blɝ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

The land lurched around him, grasses speeding by in a flash. It was as if Perrin had leaped a hundred paces in one step. He stepped again, shooting forward. He left a faint blur behind him.

ðə ɡɹæsəz pɑɹɾəd fəɹ hɪm. ðə wɪn blu ɪn ɪz feɪs wɪð ə kʌmftəɹbəl ɹɔɹ. ðət pɹaɪməl wʊlf ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm spɑɹk tə weɪkfəlnəs. pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt ðə wʊdz ən sloʊd. itʃ stɛp naʊ tʊk ɪm ə dʒʌmp ʌv oʊnli əbaʊt tɛn fit. ði ʌðɝ wʊlvz wɝ ðɛɹ, ən ðeɪ fɔɹmd ʌp ən ɹæn wɪð hɪm, ɪksaɪɾəd.

The grasses parted for him. The wind blew in his face with a comfortable roar. That primal wolf inside of him sparked to wakefulness. Perrin reached the woods and slowed. Each step now took him a jump of only about ten feet. The other wolves were there, and they formed up and ran with him, excited.

tu fit, jʌŋ bʊl? oʊk dænsɝ æskt. ʃi wɑz ə juθfəl fimeɪl, hɝ pɛl soʊ laɪɾ əz tə bi ɔlmoʊst waɪt, wɪð ə stʃɹik ə blæk ɹʌnɪŋ əlɔŋ əɹ ɹaɪt saɪd.

Two feet, Young Bull? Oak Dancer asked. She was a youthful female, her pelt so light as to be almost white, with a streak of black running along her right side.

hi dɪdn ænsɝ, ðoʊ hi dɪɾ əlaʊ hɪmsɛlf tə ɹʌn wɪð əm θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. wʌt hæd sim laɪk ə smɔl stæn hæd bɪkʌm ən ɪkspænsɪv fɔɹəst. pɛɹɪn muv pæs tʃɹʌŋks ən fɝnz, bɛɹli filɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ ɪz fit.

He didn't answer, though he did allow himself to run with them through the trees. What had seemed like a small stand had become an expansive forest. Perrin moved past trunks and ferns, barely feeling the ground beneath his feet.

ðɪs wɑz ðə weɪ tə ɹʌn. paʊɝfəl. ɛnɝdʒɛɾɪk. hi loʊpt oʊvɝ fɔlən lɔɡz, hɪz dʒʌmps teɪkɪŋ ɪm soʊ haɪ ðəɾ ɪz hɛɹ bɹʌʃt ðə bɑɾəmz ə ðə bɹæntʃəz. hi lændəd smuðli. ðə fɔɹəst wɑz hɪz. ɪt bɪlɔŋ tə hɪm, ən i ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪt.

This was the way to run. Powerful. Energetic. He loped over fallen logs, his jumps taking him so high that his hair brushed the bottoms of the branches. He landed smoothly. The forest was his. It belonged to him, and he understood it.

hɪz wɝiz bɪɡæn tə mɛlt əweɪ. hi əlaʊd hɪmsɛlf tə æksɛp θɪŋz əz ðeɪ wɝ, nɑɾ əz wʌɾ i fɪɹd ðeɪ maɪt bɪkʌm. ðiz wʊlvz wɝ ɪz bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz. ə ɹʌnɪŋ wʊlf ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld wɑz ə mæstɝwɝk ə bæləns ən kəntʃɹoʊl. hɪɹ - wɛɹ ðə ɹulz ə neɪtʃɝ bɛn tə ðɛɹ wɪl -  ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ mɔɹ. wʊlvz baʊndəd tə ðə saɪdz ən lɛpt ɔf tʃɹiz, nʌθɪŋ hoʊldɪŋ əm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. səm æktʃəli  tʊk tə ðə bɹæntʃəz, sɔɹɪŋ fɹəm lɪm tə lɪm.

His worries began to melt away. He allowed himself to accept things as they were, not as what he feared they might become. These wolves were his brothers and sisters. A running wolf in the real world was a masterwork of balance and control. Here - where the rules of nature bent to their will -  they were far more. Wolves bounded to the sides and leaped off trees, nothing holding them to the ground. Some actually took to the branches, soaring from limb to limb.

ɪt wɑz ɪɡzɪlɝeɪɾɪŋ. hæɾ i ɛvɝ fɛl soʊ əlaɪv? soʊ mʌtʃ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn hɪm, jɛt mæstɝ ʌv ɪɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm? ðə ɹʌf, ɹiɡəl lɛðɝlifs wɝ ɪntɝspɝst wɪð ju ən ði əkeɪʒənəl ɔɹnəmɛntɪd spɪswʊɾ ɪn fʊl blum. hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ði ɛɹ əz i pæst wʌn ə ðiz, ðə wɪn ə hɪz pæsɪŋ pʊlɪŋ ə stɔɹm ə kɹɪmzən blɑsəmz fɹəm ðə bɹæntʃəz. ðeɪ sɝdʒd ɝaʊn ɪm ɪn ə swɝlɪŋ blɝ, kɑɾ ɪn ðə kɝəns, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ɪm ɪn ðɛɹ swit sɛnt.

It was exhilarating. Had he ever felt so alive? So much a part of the world around him, yet master of it at the same time? The rough, regal leatherleafs were interspersed with yew and the occasional ornamented spicewood in full bloom. He threw himself into the air as he passed one of these, the wind of his passing pulling a storm of crimson blossoms from the branches. They surged around him in a swirling blur, caught in the currents, cradling him in their sweet scent.

ðə wʊlvz bɪɡæn tə haʊl. tə mɛn, wʌn haʊl wɑz laɪk ənʌðɝ. tə pɛɹɪn, itʃ wɑz dɪstɪŋkt.

The wolves began to howl. To men, one howl was like another. To Perrin, each was distinct.

ðiz wɝ ðə haʊlz ə plɛʒɝ, ði ɪnɪʃieɪʃən ʌv ə hʌnt.

These were the howls of pleasure, the initiation of a hunt.

weɪt. ðɪs ɪz wʌɾ aɪ fɪɹd! aɪ kænɑt lɛt maɪsɛlf bi tʃɹæpt. aɪm ə mæn, nɑɾ ə wʊlf ət ðət moʊmənt, haʊɛvɝ, hi kɑt sɛn ʌv ə stæɡ. ə maɪɾi ænəməl, wɝði pɹeɪ. ɪt hæd pæs ðɪs weɪ ɹisənli.

Wait. This is what I feared! I cannot let myself be trapped. I am a man, not a wolf At that moment, however, he caught scent of a stag. A mighty animal, worthy prey. It had passed this way recently.

pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə ɹistʃɹeɪn hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ æntɪsəpeɪʃən pɹuv tu stʃɹɔŋ. hi tɔɹ ɔf daʊn ðə ɡeɪm tʃɹeɪl æftɝ ðə sɛnt. ðə wʊlvz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ hɑpɝ, dɪd nɑt ɹeɪs əhɛɾ ə hɪm. ðeɪ ɹæn wɪð hɪm, ðɛɹ sɛns plizd əz ðeɪ lɛɾ ɪm teɪk ðə lɛd.

Perrin tried to restrain himself, but anticipation proved too strong. He tore off down the game trail after the scent. The wolves, including Hopper, did not race ahead of him. They ran with him, their scents pleased as they let him take the lead.

hi wɑz ðə hɛɹəld, ðə pɔɪnt, ðə tɪp ə ði ətæk. ðə hʌn ɹɔɹd bɪhaɪn hɪm. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf i lɛd ðə kɹæʃɪŋ weɪvz ə ði oʊʃən ɪtsɛlf. bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlsoʊ hoʊldɪŋ əm bæk.

He was the herald, the point, the tip of the attack. The hunt roared behind him. It was as if he led the crashing waves of the ocean itself. But he was also holding them back.

aɪ kænɑt meɪk əm sloʊ fəɹ mi, pɛɹɪn θɔt.

I cannot make them slow for me, Perrin thought.

ən ðən i wɑz ɑn ɔl fɔɹz, hɪz baʊ tɔst əsaɪɾ ən fɝɡɑɾən, hɪz hænz ən lɛɡz bɪkʌmɪŋ pɔz. ðoʊz bɪhaɪn ɪm haʊld ənu ət ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ɪt. jʌŋ bʊl hæd tʃɹuli dʒɔɪn ðɛm.

And then he was on all fours, his bow tossed aside and forgotten, his hands and legs becoming paws. Those behind him howled anew at the glory of it. Young Bull had truly joined them.

ðə stæɡ wɑz əhɛd. jʌŋ bʊl pɪkt ɪɾ aʊt θɹu ðə tʃɹiz; ɪt wɑz ə bɹɪljənt waɪt, wɪð ə ɹæk ʌv ət lis twɛnti-sɪks pɔɪns, ðə wɪntɝ fɛlt wɔɹn əweɪ. ən ɪt wɑz ɪnɔɹməs, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə hɔɹs. ðə stæɡ tɝnd, lʊkɪŋ ʃɑɹpli ət ðə pæk. ɪt mɛt pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən i smɛld ɪts əlɑɹm.

The stag was ahead. Young Bull picked it out through the trees; it was a brilliant white, with a rack of at least twenty-six points, the winter felt worn away. And it was enormous, larger than a horse. The stag turned, looking sharply at the pack. It met Perrins eyes, and he smelled its alarm.

ðɛn, wɪð ə paʊɝfəl sɝdʒ ʌv ɪts haɪn lɛɡz - flæŋks tɔt wɪð mʌsəlz -  ðə stæɡ lɛpt ɔf ðə tʃɹeɪl.

Then, with a powerful surge of its hind legs - flanks taut with muscles -  the stag leaped off the trail.

jʌŋ bʊl haʊld ɪz tʃælənʒ, ɹeɪsɪŋ θɹu ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ɪn pɝsut. ðə ɡɹeɪt waɪt stæɡ baʊndəɾ ɑn, itʃ lip teɪkɪŋ ɪt twɛnti peɪsɪz. ɪt nɛvɝ hɪɾ ə bɹæntʃ əɹ lɔst ɪts fʊɾɪŋ, dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɹɛtʃɝəs fɔɹəs flɔɹ koʊɾəd wɪð slɪk mɔs.

Young Bull howled his challenge, racing through the underbrush in pursuit. The great white stag bounded on, each leap taking it twenty paces. It never hit a branch or lost its footing, despite the treacherous forest floor coated with slick moss.

jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd wɪð pɹisɪʒən, pleɪsɪŋ ɪz pɔz wɛɹ hʊvz hæd fɔlən dʒʌs moʊməns bɪfɔɹ, mætʃɪŋ itʃ stʃɹaɪɾ ɪɡzækli. hi kəd hɪɹ ðə stæɡ pæntɪŋ, kəd si ðə swɛt foʊmɪŋ ɑn ɪts koʊt, kəd smɛl ɪts fɪɹ.

Young Bull followed with precision, placing his paws where hooves had fallen just moments before, matching each stride exactly. He could hear the stag panting, could see the sweat foaming on its coat, could smell its fear.

bʌt noʊ. jʌŋ bʊl wəd nɑɾ æksɛp ði ɪnfɪɹiɝ vɪktɝi ʌv ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz pɹeɪ tə ɪɡzɔstʃən. hi wəd teɪs ðə blʌɾ ə ðə θɹoʊt, pʌmpɪŋ fʊl fɔɹs fɹəm ə hɛlθi hɑɹt. hi wəd bɛst ɪz pɹeɪ ɪn ɪts pɹaɪm.

But no. Young Bull would not accept the inferior victory of running his prey to exhaustion. He would taste the blood of the throat, pumping full force from a healthy heart. He would best his prey in its prime.

hi bɪɡæn tə vɛɹi hɪz lips, nɑt fɑloʊɪŋ ðə stæɡz ɪɡzæk pæθ. hi niɾəd tə bi əhɛd, nɑt fɑloʊ!

He began to vary his leaps, not following the stag's exact path. He needed to be ahead, not follow!

ðə stæɡz sɛnt ɡɹu mɔɹ əlɑɹmd. ðət dʒɹoʊv jʌŋ bʊl tə ɡɹeɪɾɝ spid. ðə stæɡ boʊltəd tə ðə ɹaɪt, ən jʌŋ bʊl lɛpt, hɪɾɪŋ ən əpɹaɪt tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk wɪð ɔl fɔɹ pɔz ən pʊʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf saɪdweɪz tə tʃeɪnʒ dɝɛkʃənz. hɪz tɝn ɡeɪn ɪm ə fɹækʃən ʌv ə hɑɹtbit.

The stag's scent grew more alarmed. That drove Young Bull to greater speed. The stag bolted to the right, and Young Bull leaped, hitting an upright tree trunk with all four paws and pushing himself sideways to change directions. His turn gained him a fraction of a heartbeat.

sun i wɑz baʊndɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl bɹɛθ bɪhaɪn ðə stæɡ, itʃ lip bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm wɪðɪn ɪntʃəz ʌv ɪts hʊvz. hi haʊld, ən ɪz bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz ɹɪplaɪd fɹəm dʒʌs bɪhaɪnd. ðɪs hʌnt wɑz ɔl ə ðɛm.

Soon he was bounding a single breath behind the stag, each leap bringing him within inches of its hooves. He howled, and his brothers and sisters replied from just behind. This hunt was all of them.

əz wʌn.

As one.

bʌt jʌŋ bʊl lɛd.

But Young Bull led.

hɪz haʊl bɪkeɪm ə ɡɹaʊl ə tʃɹaɪəmf əz ðə stæɡ tɝn əɡɛn. ðə tʃæns hæd kʌm! jʌŋ bʊl lɛpt oʊvɝ ə lɔɡ ən siz ðə stæɡz nɛk ɪn ɪz dʒɔz. hi kəd teɪs ðə swɛt, ðə fɝ, ðə wɔɹm blʌd bɪniθ pulɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz fæŋz. hɪz weɪt θɹu ðə stæɡ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. əz ðeɪ ɹoʊld, jʌŋ bʊl kɛpt ɪz ɡɹɪp, fɔɹsɪŋ ðə stæɡ tə ðə fɔɹəs flɔɹ, ɪts skɪn leɪst skɑɹlət wɪð blʌd.

His howl became a growl of triumph as the stag turned again. The chance had come! Young Bull leaped over a log and seized the stag's neck in his jaws. He could taste the sweat, the fur, the warm blood beneath pooling around his fangs. His weight threw the stag to the ground. As they rolled, Young Bull kept his grip, forcing the stag to the forest floor, its skin laced scarlet with blood.

ðə wʊlvz haʊld ɪn vɪktɝi, ən i lɛt ɡoʊ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɪntɛndɪŋ tə baɪɾ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə nɛk ən kɪl. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls. ðə fɔɹəst wɑz ɡɔn. ðə haʊlz feɪɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə kɪl. ðə swit kɪl.

The wolves howled in victory, and he let go for a moment, intending to bite at the front of the neck and kill. There was nothing else. The forest was gone. The howls faded. There was only the kill. The sweet kill.

ə fɔɹm kɹæʃt ɪndə hɪm, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪm bæk ɪndə ðə bɹʌʃ. jʌŋ bʊl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, deɪzd, snɑɹlɪŋ. ənʌðɝ wʊlf hæd stɑp hɪm. hɑpɝ! waɪ?

A form crashed into him, throwing him back into the brush. Young Bull shook his head, dazed, snarling. Another wolf had stopped him. Hopper! Why?

ðə stæɡ baʊndəd tə ɪts fit, ən ðən baʊndəɾ ɔf θɹu ðə fɔɹəst əɡɛn. jʌŋ bʊl haʊld ɪn fjʊɹi ən ɹeɪdʒ, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə ɹʌn æftɝ ɪt. əɡɛn hɑpɝ lɛpt, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz weɪɾ əɡɛns jʌŋ bʊl.

The stag bounded to its feet, and then bounded off through the forest again. Young Bull howled in fury and rage, preparing to run after it. Again Hopper leaped, throwing his weight against Young Bull.

ɪf ɪt daɪz hɪɹ, ɪt daɪz ðə læs dɛθ, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ðɪs hʌn ɪz dʌn, jʌŋ bʊl. wɪl hʌn ənʌðɝ taɪm.

If it dies here, it dies the last death, Hopper sent. This hunt is done, Young Bull. We will hunt another time.

jʌŋ bʊl nɪɹli tɝn tə ətæk hɑpɝ. bʌt noʊ. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd ðət wʌns, ən ɪt hæd bɪn ə mɪsteɪk. hi wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊlf. hi -  pɛɹɪn leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, teɪstɪŋ blʌd ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪz oʊn, ɪkshəlɪŋ dipli, hɪz feɪs dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɪð swɛt. hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz niz, ðən sæt daʊn, pæntɪŋ, ʃeɪkɪŋ fɹəm ðət bjuɾəfəl, tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ hʌnt.

Young Bull nearly turned to attack Hopper. But no. He had tried that once, and it had been a mistake. He was not a wolf. He -  Perrin lay on the ground, tasting blood that was not his own, exhaling deeply, his face dripping with sweat. He pushed himself to his knees, then sat down, panting, shaking from that beautiful, terrifying hunt.

ði ʌðɝ wʊlvz sæt daʊn, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt spik. hɑpɝ leɪ bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn, sɛɾɪŋ ɪz ɡɹɪzəl hɛɾ ɑn eɪdʒ pɔz.

The other wolves sat down, but they did not speak. Hopper lay beside Perrin, setting his grizzled head on aged paws.

"ðæt," pɛɹɪn faɪnəli sɛd, "ɪz wʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ."

"That," Perrin finally said, "is what I fear."

noʊ, jə də nɑt fɪɹ ɪt, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

No, you do not fear it, Hopper sent.

"jɔɹ tɛlɪŋ mi wʌɾ aɪ fil?"

"You're telling me what I feel?"

jə də nɑt smɛl əfɹeɪd, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

You do not smell afraid, Hopper sent.

pɛɹɪn leɪ bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə bɹæntʃəz əbʌv, twɪɡz ən livz kɹʌmplɪŋ bɪniθ hɪm. hɪz hɑɹt θʌmp fɹəm ðə tʃeɪs. "aɪ wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðɛn."

Perrin lay back, staring up at the branches above, twigs and leaves crumpling beneath him. His heart thumped from the chase. "I worry about it, then."

wɝi ɪz nɑt ðə seɪm əz fɪɹ, hɑpɝ sɛnt. waɪ seɪ wʌn ən fil ði ʌðɝ? wɝi, wɝi, wɝi.

Worry is not the same as fear, Hopper sent. Why say one and feel the other? worry, worry, worry.

ɪts ɔl ðət jə du.

It is all that you do.

"noʊ. aɪ ɔlsoʊ kɪl. ɪf jəɹ gɑnə titʃ mi tə mæstɝ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, ɪts gɑnə hæpən laɪk ðɪs?"

"No. I also kill. If you're going to teach me to master the wolf dream, it's going to happen like this?"

jɛs.

Yes.

pɛɹɪn lʊk tə ðə saɪd. ðə stæɡz blʌd hæd spɪld ɑn ə dʒɹaɪ lɔɡ, dɑɹknəs sipɪŋ ɪndə ðə wʊd. lɝnɪŋ ðɪs weɪ wəd pʊʃ ɪm tə ðə vɛɹi ɛdʒ ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə wʊlf.

Perrin looked to the side. The stag's blood had spilled on a dry log, darkness seeping into the wood. Learning this way would push him to the very edge of becoming a wolf.

bʌɾ i hæd bɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðɪs ɪʃu fəɹ tu lɔŋ, meɪkɪŋ hɔɹsʃuz ɪn ðə fɔɹdʒ waɪl livɪŋ ðə moʊs dɪfəkəlt ən dɪmændɪŋ pisəz əloʊn, ʌn-tʌtʃt. hi ɹɪlaɪɾ ɑn ðə paʊɝz ə sɛn hid bɪn ɡɪvən, ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt tə wʊlvz wən i niɾəd əm - bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz hiɾ ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm.

But he had been avoiding this issue for too long, making horseshoes in the forge while leaving the most difficult and demanding pieces alone, un-touched. He relied on the powers of scent he'd been given, reaching out to wolves when he needed them - but otherwise he'd ignored them.

jə kʊdn meɪk ə θɪŋ əntɪl jə ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪts pɑɹts. hi wʊdnt noʊ haʊ tə dil wɪð - əɹ ɹɪdʒɛkt - ðə wʊlf ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm əntɪl i ʌndɝstʊd ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

You couldn't make a thing until you understood its parts. He wouldn't know how to deal with - or reject - the wolf inside him until he understood the wolf dream.

"vɛɹi wɛl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "soʊ bi ɪt."

"Very well," Perrin said. "So be it."

ɡɑləd kæntɝd staʊt θɹu ðə kæmp. ɑn ɔl saɪdz, tʃɪlʒɹən ɪɹɛktəd tɛns ən dʌɡ faɪɹɛpɪts, pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə naɪt. hɪz mɛn mɑɹtʃt ɔlmoʊst əntɪl naɪtfɔl itʃ deɪ, ðən ɝoʊz ɝli ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ðə sunɝ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ændɝ, ðə bɛɾɝ.

Galad cantered Stout through the camp. On all sides, Children erected tents and dug firepits, preparing for the night. His men marched almost until nightfall each day, then arose early in the morning. The sooner they reached Andor, the better.

ðoʊz laɪt-kɝst swɑmps wɝ bɪhaɪn ðɛm; naʊ ðeɪ tʃɹævəld oʊvɝ oʊpən ɡɹæslænz. pɝhæps ɪt wʊɾə bɪn fæstɝ tə kʌɾ ist ən kætʃ wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt haɪweɪz tə ðə nɔɹθ, bʌt ðət wʊdn bi seɪf. bɛs tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðə muvməns ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz ɑɹmiz ən ðə sintʃæn. ðə laɪt wəd ʃaɪn əpɑn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌt mɔɹ ðən wʌn væljən hɪɹoʊ hæd daɪd wɪðɪn ðət laɪt. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz noʊ deɪnʒɝ ə dɛθ, ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ bɹeɪvɝi, bʌt ɡɑləd wəd ɹæðɝ əv ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ɪm waɪl i kəntɪnjud tə dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ.

Those Light-cursed swamps were behind them; now they traveled over open grasslands. Perhaps it would have been faster to cut east and catch one of the great highways to the north, but that wouldn't be safe. Best to stay away from the movements of the Dragon Reborn's armies and the Seanchan. The Light would shine upon the Children, but more than one valiant hero had died within that Light. If there was no danger of death, there could be no bravery, but Galad would rather have the Light shine on him while he continued to draw breath.

ðeɪ hæd kæmp nɪɹ ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊɾ ən wəd kɹɔs ɪɾ ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ tə kəntɪnju nɔɹθ. hi hæd sɛn ə pətʃɹoʊl tə wɑtʃ ðə ɹoʊd. hi wɑntəd tə noʊ wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹæfɪk ðə haɪweɪ wɑz dʒɹɔɪŋ, ən i wɑz ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ niɾ ə səplaɪz.

They had camped near the Jehannah Road and would cross it on the morrow to continue north. He had sent a patrol to watch the road. He wanted to know what kind of traffic the highway was drawing, and he was in particular need of supplies.

ɡɑləd kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn ɪz ɹaʊnz θɹu kæmp, əkʌmpənid baɪ ə hændfʊl ə maʊntəɾ ətɛndəns, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði eɪks ə hɪz vɛɹiəs wunz. ðə kæmp wɑz ɔɹɾɝli ən nit. ðə tɛns wɝ ɡɹup baɪ lidʒən, ðən sɛɾ ʌp fɔɹmɪŋ kənsɛntʃɹɪk ɹɪŋz wɪð noʊ stʃɹeɪt pæθweɪz. ðət wɑz ɪntɛndəd tə kənfjuz ən sloʊ ətækɝz.

Galad continued on his rounds through camp, accompanied by a handful of mounted attendants, ignoring the aches of his various wounds. The camp was orderly and neat. The tents were grouped by legion, then set up forming concentric rings with no straight pathways. That was intended to confuse and slow attackers.

ə sɛkʃən ə ðə kæmp leɪ ɛmpti nɪɹ ðə mɪɾəl. ə hoʊl ɪn ðə fɔɹmeɪʃən wɛɹ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz hæd wʌns sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ tɛns. hi hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ði ɑustʃənɝz spɹɛɾ aʊt, tu əsaɪn tə itʃ kʌmpəni. ɪf ðə kwɛstʃənɝz wɝ nɑt sɛɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm ði ʌðɝz, pɝhæps ðeɪ wəd fil mɔɹ kɪnʃɪp wɪð ði ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən. ɡɑləd meɪɾ ə noʊt tə hɪmsɛlf tə dʒɹɔ ʌp ə nu kæmp leɪaʊt, ɪlɪməneɪɾɪŋ ðət hoʊl.

A section of the camp lay empty near the middle. A hole in the formation where the Questioners had once set up their tents. He had ordered the Ouestioners spread out, two assigned to each company. If the Questioners were not set apart from the others, perhaps they would feel more kinship with the other Children. Galad made a note to himself to draw up a new camp layout, eliminating that hole.

ɡɑləɾ ən ɪz kəmpænjənz kəntɪnjud θɹu ðə kæmp. hi ɹoʊd tə bi sin, ən mɛn səluɾəd əz i pæst. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd wɛl ðə wɝdz ðət ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd wʌns sɛd: moʊst ə ðə taɪm, ə dʒɛnɝəlz moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt fʌŋkʃən wɑz nɑt tə meɪk dɪsɪʒənz, bʌt tə ɹimaɪn mɛn ðət sʌmwʌn wəd meɪk dɪsɪʒənz.

Galad and his companions continued through the camp. He rode to be seen, and men saluted as he passed. He remembered well the words that Gareth Bryne had once said: Most of the time, a general's most important function was not to make decisions, but to remind men that someone would make decisions.

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," sɛd wʌn ə hɪz kəmpænjənz. bɹændəl vɔɹdɛɹiən. hi wɑz ən oʊldɝ mæn, ɛldəst ə ðə lɔɹdz kæptən u sɝvd ʌndɝ ɡɑləd. "aɪ wɪʃ jə wəd ɹikənsɪɾɝ sɛndɪŋ ðɪs mɪsɪv."

"My Lord Captain Commander," said one of his companions. Brandel Vordarian. He was an older man, eldest of the Lords Captain who served under Galad. "I wish you would reconsider sending this missive."

vɔɹdɛɹiən ɹoʊd dɝɛkli bɪsaɪd ɡɑləd, wɪð tʃɹɑm ɑn ɪz ʌðɝ saɪd. lɔɹdz kæptən ɡəlivɝ ən hɑɹnɪʃ ɹoʊd bɪhaɪnd, wɪðɪn ɪɹʃɑt, ən bɔɹnhəl fɑloʊd, æktɪŋ əz ɡɑləɾ ɛs bɑɾiɡɑɹd fəɹ ðə deɪ.

Vordarian rode directly beside Galad, with Trom on his other side. Lords Captain Golever and Harnesh rode behind, within earshot, and Bornhald followed, acting as Galad s bodyguard for the day.

"ðə lɛɾɝ mʌs bi sɛnt," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"The letter must be sent," Galad said.

"ɪt simz fulhɑɹɾi, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," vɔɹdɛɹiən kəntɪnjud. klin-ʃeɪvən, wɪð sɪlvɝ wɑʃɪŋ ɪz ɡoʊldən hɛɹ, ði ændɔɝən wɑz ən ɪnɔɹməs skwɛɹ ʌv ə mæn. ɡɑləd wɑz veɪɡli fəmɪljɝ wɪð vɔɹdɛɹiənz fæmli, maɪnɝ noʊbəlz u hæd bɪn ɪnvɑlvd ɪn ɪz mʌðɝz kɔɹt.

"It seems foolhardy, my Lord Captain Commander," Vordarian continued. Clean-shaven, with silver washing his golden hair, the Andoran was an enormous square of a man. Galad was vaguely familiar with Vordarian's family, minor nobles who had been involved in his mother's court.

oʊnli ə ful ɹəfjuz tə lɪsən tə ædvaɪs fɹəm ðoʊz oʊldɝ ən waɪzɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf. bʌɾ oʊnli ə ful tʊk ɔl ə ði ædvaɪs ɡɪvən hɪm.

Only a fool refused to listen to advice from those older and wiser than himself. But only a fool took all of the advice given him.

"pɝhæps fulhɑɹɾi," ɡɑləd ɹɪplaɪd. "bʌɾ ɪts ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə du." ðə lɛɾɝ wɑz ədʒɹɛs tə ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ kwɛstʃənɝz ən tʃɪlʒɹən ʌndɝ ðə kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə sintʃæn; ðəɹ wəd bi səm u hæd nɑt kʌm wɪð æsu-nɑwə. ɪn ðə lɛɾɝ, ɡɑləɾ ɪkspleɪnd wʌt hæd hæpənd, ən kəmændəɾ əm tə ɹipɔɹt tə hɪm əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ɛni wəd kʌm, bʌt ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə noʊ wʌt hæd hæpənd.

"Perhaps foolhardy," Galad replied. "But it is the right thing to do." The letter was addressed to the remaining Questioners and Children under the control of the Seanchan; there would be some who had not come with Asu-nawa. In the letter, Galad explained what had happened, and commanded them to report to him as soon as possible. It was unlikely any would come, but the others had a right to know what had happened.

lɔɹd vɔɹdɛɹiən saɪd, ðən meɪd weɪ əz hɑɹnɪʃ ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd ɡɑləd. ðə bɔl mæn skɹætʃt æbsənli ət ðə skɑɹ tɪsju wɛɹ ɪz lɛft ɪɹ hæd bɪn. "ɪnʌf əbaʊt ðɪs lɛɾɝ, vɔɹdɛɹiən. ðə weɪ jə ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊɾ ɪt tʃɹaɪz maɪ peɪʃəns." fɹəm ɡɑlədz ɑbzɝveɪʃən, ðəɹ wɝ mɛni θɪŋz ðət tʃɹaɪd ðə mʊɹændiənz peɪʃəns.

Lord Vordarian sighed, then made way as Harnesh rode up beside Galad. The bald man scratched absently at the scar tissue where his left ear had been. "Enough about this letter, Vordarian. The way you go on about it tries my patience." From Galad's observation, there were many things that tried the Murandian's patience.

"ju hæv ʌðɝ mæɾɝz jə wɪʃ tə dɪskʌs, aɪ əsum?" ɡɑləd nɑɾəd tə ə pɛɹ ə tʃɪlʒɹən kʌɾɪŋ lɔɡz, hu stɑp ðɛɹ wɝk tə səlut hɪm.

"You have other matters you wish to discuss, I assume?" Galad nodded to a pair of Children cutting logs, who stopped their work to salute him.

"ju toʊl tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ, ən ʌðɝz ðət jə plæn tə əlaɪ əs wɪð ðə wɪtʃəz ə tɑɹ vəlɑn!"

"You told Child Bornhald, Child Byar, and others that you plan to ally us with the witches of Tar Valon!"

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. "aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðət ðə noʊʃən maɪt bi tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf jə kənsɪɾɝ, jəl si ðəɾ ɪts ði oʊnli ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən."

Galad nodded. "I understand that the notion might be troubling, but if you consider, you will see that it is the only right decision."

"bʌt ðə wɪtʃəz ɑɹ ivəl!"

"But the witches are evil!"

"pɝhæps," ɡɑləd sɛd. wʌns, hi maɪɾ əv dɪnaɪd ðæt. bʌt lɪsnɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən, ən kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wʌt ðoʊz ət tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd dʌn tə  hɪz sɪstɝ, wɑz meɪkɪŋ ɪm θɪŋk i maɪt bi tu sɑft ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "haʊɛvɝ, lɔɹd hɑɹnɪʃ, ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ivəl, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkənt wən kəmpɛɹd tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmz. dʒju dɪnaɪ ðɪs?"

"Perhaps," Galad said. Once, he might have denied that. But listening to the other Children, and considering what those at Tar Valon had done to | his sister, was making him think he might be too soft on the Aes Sedai. "However, Lord Harnesh, if they are evil, they are insignificant when compared to the Dark One. The Last Battle comes. Do you deny this?"

hɑɹnɪʃ ən ði ʌðɝz lʊkt ʌp ət ðə skaɪ. ðət dʒɹɪɹi oʊvɝkæs hæd stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ wiks naʊ.

Harnesh and the others looked up at the sky. That dreary overcast had stretched for weeks now.

ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ənʌðɝ mæn hæd fɔlən tə ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪlnəs wɛɹ biɾəlz hæd kʌm fɹəm ɪz maʊθ əz i kɔft. ðɛɹ fud stɔɹz wɝ dɪmɪnɪʃɪŋ əz mɔɹ ən mɔɹ wɑz faʊn spɔɪld.

The day before, another man had fallen to a strange illness where beetles had come from his mouth as he coughed. Their food stores were diminishing as more and more was found spoiled.

"noʊ, aɪ də nɑt dɪnaɪ ɪt," hɑɹnɪʃ mʌɾɝd.

"No, I do not deny it," Harnesh muttered.

"ðɛn jə ʃəd ɹɪdʒɔɪs," ɡɑləd sɛd, "fɔɹ ðə weɪ ɪz klɪɹ. wi mʌs faɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl. əɹ liɾɝʃɪp ðəɹ meɪ ʃoʊ ðə weɪ ʌv laɪt tə mɛni hu hæv spɝn ʌs. bʌɾ ɪf ɪt dʌz nɑt, wɪl faɪt ɹəɡɑɹdləs, fəɹ ɪts əɹ duɾi. dʒju dɪnaɪ ðɪs, lɔɹd kæptən?"

"Then you should rejoice," Galad said, "for the way is clear. We must fight at the Last Battle. Our leadership there may show the way of Light to many who have spurned us. But if it does not, we will fight regardless, for it is our duty. Do you deny this, Lord Captain?"

"əɡɛn, noʊ. bʌt ðə wɪtʃəz, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ?"

"Again, no. But the witches, my Lord Captain Commander?"

ɡɑləd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ kən θɪŋk ə noʊ weɪ ɝaʊn ɪt. wi niɾ ælaɪz. lʊk əbaʊt ju, lɔɹd hɑɹnɪʃ. haʊ mɛni tʃɪlʒɹən də wi hæv? ivən wɪð ɹisən ɹəkɹuts, wəɹ ʌndɝ twɛnti θaʊzənd.

Galad shook his head. "I can think of no way around it. We need allies. Look about you, Lord Harnesh. How many Children do we have? Even with recent recruits, we are under twenty thousand.

əɹ fɔɹtʃɹəs əz bɪn teɪkən. wəɹ wɪθaʊt sʌkɝ əɹ əlidʒəns, ən ðə ɡɹeɪt neɪʃənz ə ðə wɝld ɹɛvaɪl ʌs. noʊ, doʊn dɪnaɪ ɪt! jə noʊ ðəɾ ɪts tʃɹu."

Our fortress has been taken. We are without succor or allegiance, and the great nations of the world revile us. No, don't deny it! You know that it is true."

ɡɑləd mɛt ði aɪz ə ðoʊz ɝaʊn hɪm, ən wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ nɑɾəd.

Galad met the eyes of those around him, and one by one they nodded.

"ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɑɹ ət fɔlt," hɑɹnɪʃ mʌɾɝd.

"The Questioners are at fault," Harnesh muttered.

"pɑɹɾ ə ðə bleɪm ɪz ðɛɹz," ɡɑləɾ əɡɹid. "bʌɾ ɪts ɔlsoʊ kəz ðoʊz u wəd də ivəl lʊk wɪð dɪsɡʌst ən ɹɪzɛnmənt əpɑn ðoʊz u stæn fəɹ wʌɾ ɪz ɹaɪt."

"Part of the blame is theirs," Galad agreed. "But it is also because those who would do evil look with disgust and resentment upon those who stand for what is right."

ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd.

The others nodded.

"wi mʌs tʃɹɛd kɛɹfəli," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ɪn ðə pæst, ðə boʊlnəs - ən pɝhæps oʊvɝiɡɝnəs -  ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əz eɪliəneɪɾəd ðoʊz u ʃʊɾə bɪn əɹ ælaɪz. maɪ mʌðɝ ɔlweɪz sɛd ðəɾ ə vɪktɝi ʌv dɪploʊməsi dɪd nɑt kʌm wən ɛvɹiwʌn ɡɑt wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd - ðət meɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn əsum ðeɪd ɡɑɾən ðə bɛɾɝ ə hɝ, wɪtʃ ɛnkɝɪdʒ mɔɹ ɪkstʃɹævəɡən dɪmænz. ðə tʃɹɪk ɪz nɑt tə sæɾəsfaɪ ɛvɹiwʌn, bʌt tə liv ɛvɹiwʌn filɪŋ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə bɛs pɑsəbəl ɹɪzʌlt. ðeɪ mʌs bi sæɾəsfaɪd ɪnʌf tə də əz jə wɪʃ, jɛt dɪsæɾəsfaɪd ɪnʌf tə noʊ ðət jə bɛstɪd ðɛm."

"We must tread carefully," Galad said. "In the past, the boldness - and perhaps overeagerness -  of the Children has alienated those who should have been our allies. My mother always said that a victory of diplomacy did not come when everyone got what they wanted - that made everyone assume they'd gotten the better of her, which encouraged more extravagant demands. The trick is not to satisfy everyone, but to leave everyone feeling they reached the best possible result. They must be satisfied enough to do as you wish, yet dissatisfied enough to know that you bested them."

"ænd wʌt dʌz ðɪs əv tə də wɪð ʌs?" ɡəlivɝ sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "wi fɑloʊ noʊ kwin əɹ kɪŋ."

"And what does this have to do with us?" Golever said from behind. "We follow no queen or king."

"jɛs," ɡɑləd sɛd, "æn ðət fɹaɪɾənz mɑnɑɹks. aɪ ɡɹu ʌp ɪn ðə kɔɹɾ ʌv ændɝ. aɪ noʊ haʊ maɪ mʌðɝ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ɪn ɛvɹi dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm, ʃi iðɝ ɡɹu fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd əɹ dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ʃi hæd tə səpɹɛs əm æbsəlutli. wi kænɑɾ əfɔɹɾ iðɝ ɹiækʃən! ðə mɑnɑɹks ə ðiz lænz mʌst ɹɪspɛkt ʌs, nɑt heɪɾ ʌs."

"Yes," Galad said, "and that frightens monarchs. I grew up in the court of Andor. I know how my mother regarded the Children. In every dealing with them, she either grew frustrated or decided that she had to suppress them absolutely. We cannot afford either reaction! The monarchs of these lands must respect us, not hate us."

"dɑɹkfɹɛnz," hɑɹnɪʃ mʌɾɝd.

"Darkfriends," Harnesh muttered.

"maɪ mʌðɝ wɑz noʊ dɑɹkfɹɛnd," ɡɑləd sɛd kwaɪətli.

"My mother was no Darkfriend," Galad said quietly.

hɑɹnɪʃ flʌʃt. "ɛksɛptɪŋ hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs."

Harnesh flushed. "Excepting her, of course."

"ju spik laɪk ə kwɛstʃənɝ," ɡɑləd sɛd. "səspɛktɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn u əpoʊzɪz əs ə biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. mɛni ʌv əm ɑɹ ɪnfluəns baɪ ðə ʃædoʊ, bʌɾ aɪ daʊt ðəɾ ɪts kɑnʃəs. ðəɾ ɪz wɛɹ ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt wɛn ɹɔŋ. ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɔfən kəd nɑt tɛl ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ə hɑɹɾənd dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ə pɝsən u wɑz biɪŋ ɪnfluəns baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ə pɝsən u sɪmpli dɪsəɡɹid wɪð ðə tʃɪlʒɹən."

"You speak like a Questioner," Galad said. "Suspecting everyone who opposes us of being a Darkfriend. Many of them are influenced by the Shadow, but I doubt that it is conscious. That is where the Hand of the Light went wrong. The Questioners often could not tell the difference between a hardened Darkfriend, a person who was being influenced by Darkfriends, and a person who simply disagreed with the Children."

"soʊ wʌt də wi du?" vɔɹdɛɹiən æskt. "wi baʊ tə ðə wɪmz ə mɑnɑɹks?"

"So what do we do?" Vordarian asked. "We bow to the whims of monarchs?"

"aɪ doʊn jɛt noʊ wʌt tə du," ɡɑləd kənfɛst. "aɪ wɪl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt. ðə ɹaɪt kɔɹs wɪl kʌm tə mi. wi kænɑt bɪkʌm læpdɔɡz tə kɪŋz ən kwinz. ən jɛt, θɪŋk ʌv wʌt wi kəɾ ətʃiv ɪnsaɪɾ ʌv ə neɪʃənz baʊndɝiz ɪf wi kəɾ ækt wɪθaʊt niɾɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ lidʒən tə ɪntɪmɪdeɪt ðət neɪʃənz ɹulɝ."

"I don't yet know what to do," Galad confessed. "I will think on it. The right course will come to me. We cannot become lapdogs to kings and queens. And yet, think of what we could achieve inside of a nations boundaries if we could act without needing an entire legion to intimidate that nation's ruler."

ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd ət ðɪs, θɔtfəl.

The others nodded at this, thoughtful.

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ!" ə vɔɪs kɔld.

"My Lord Captain Commander!" a voice called.

ɡɑləd tɝn tə si baɪɑɝ ɑn ɪz waɪt stæljən kæntɝɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm. ðə hɔɹs hæd bɪlɔŋ tə əsunɑwə; ɡɑləd hæd ɹəfjuzd ɪt, pɹɪfɝɪŋ ɪz oʊn beɪ. ɡɑləd pʊld ɪz ɡɹup tə ə hɔlt əz ðə ɡɔnt- feɪs baɪɑɝ nɪɹd, hɪz waɪt tɑbɝd pɹɪstin. baɪɑɝ wɑzn ðə moʊs laɪkəbəl ə mɛn ɪn ðə kæmp, bʌɾ i hæd pɹuvən tə bi lɔɪəl.

Galad turned to see Byar on his white stallion cantering toward them. The horse had belonged to Asunawa; Galad had refused it, preferring his own bay. Galad pulled his group to a halt as the gaunt- faced Byar neared, his white tabard pristine. Byar wasn't the most likable of men in the camp, but he had proven to be loyal.

baɪɑɝ wɑz nɑt, haʊɛvɝ, səpoʊz tə bi ɪn ðə kæmp.

Byar was not, however, supposed to be in the camp.

"aɪ sɛt jə wɑtʃɪŋ dʒəhænə ɹoʊd, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ," ɡɑləd sɛd fɝmli. "ðæt duɾi wɑz nɑt tə ɛn fəɹ ə ɡʊd fɔɹ aʊɝz jɛt."

"I set you watching Jehannah Road, Child Byar," Galad said firmly. "That duty was not to end for a good four hours yet."

baɪɑɝ səluɾəd əz i pʊld ʌp. "maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. wi kæptʃɝɾ ə səspɪʃəs ɡɹup ə tʃɹævəlɝz ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. wʌt wəd juv əs də wɪð ðɛm?"

Byar saluted as he pulled up. "My Lord Captain Commander. We captured a suspicious group of travelers on the road. What would you have us do with them?"

"ju kæptʃɝd ðɛm?" ɡɑləɾ æskt. "aɪ sɛn jə tə wɑtʃ ðə ɹoʊd, nɑt teɪk pɹɪznɝz."

"You captured them?" Galad asked. "I sent you to watch the road, not take prisoners."

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "haʊ ɑɹ wi tə noʊ ðə kɛɹɪktɝ ə ðoʊz pæsɪŋ ənlɛs wi spik wɪð ðɛm? jə wɑntəɾ əs tə wɑtʃ fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz."

"My Lord Captain Commander," Byar said. "How are we to know the character of those passing unless we speak with them? You wanted us to watch for Darkfriends."

ɡɑləd saɪd. "aɪ wɑntəd jə tə wɑtʃ fəɹ tʃɹup muvməns əɹ mɝtʃəns wi kəɾ əpɹoʊtʃ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ."

Galad sighed. "I wanted you to watch for troop movements or merchants we could approach, Child Byar."

ðiz dɑɹkfɹɛnz əv səplaɪz," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ maɪt bi mɝtʃəns."

These Darkfriends have supplies," Byar said. "I think they might be merchants."

ɡɑləd saɪd. noʊbɑdi kəd dɪnaɪ baɪɑɝz dɛɾəkeɪʃən - hid ɹɪɾən wɪð ɡɑləd tə feɪs vɑldə wən ɪt cʊɾə mɛn ði ɛn ə hɪz kɝɪɹ. ən jɛt ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ ə θɪŋ əz biɪŋ tu zɛləs.

Galad sighed. Nobody could deny Byar's dedication - he'd ridden with Galad to face Valda when it could have meant the end of his career. And yet there was such a thing as being too zealous.

ðə θɪn ɔfəsɝ lʊk tʃɹʌbəld. wɛl, ɡɑləɾ ɛs ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz hædn bɪn pɹɪsaɪs ɪnʌf. hi wəɾ əv tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ, pɑɹ-tɪkjəlɝli wɪð baɪɑɝ. "pis," ɡɑləd sɛd, "ju dɪd noʊ ɹɔŋ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. haʊ mɛni ʌv ðiz pɹɪznɝz ɑɹ ðɛɹ?"

The thin officer looked troubled. Well, Galad s instructions hadn't been precise enough. He would have to remember that in the future, par-ticularly with Byar. "Peace," Galad said, "you did no wrong, Child Byar. How many of these prisoners are there?"

"dʌzənz, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ." baɪɑɝ lʊkt ɹɪlivd. "kʌm."

"Dozens, my Lord Captain Commander." Byar looked relieved. "Come."

hi tɝn ɪz maʊn tə lid ðə weɪ. ɔlɹɛɾi, kʊk faɪɝz wɝ spɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə pɪts, ðə sɛn ə bɝnɪŋ tɪndɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɡɑləd kɑt slaɪsəz ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən əz i ɹoʊd pæs ðə soʊlʒɝz. wʌt wəd ðə sintʃæn də wɪð ðoʊz tʃɪlʒɹən u hæd ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd? wɑz ɪt ɹɪli ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn u hæd kɑŋkɝɾ ɪljən ən tiɹ, əɹ səm fɔls dʒɹæɡən? ðəɹ wɑz tɔk ʌv ə dʒaɪɡæntɪk stoʊn fɹəm ðə skaɪ hævɪŋ stʃɹʌk ði ɝθ fɑɹ tə ðə nɔɹθ ɪn ændɝ, dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi ən livɪŋ ə kɹeɪɾɝ.

He turned his mount to lead the way. Already, cook fires were springing up in the pits, the scent of burning tinder rising in the air. Galad caught slices of conversation as he rode past the soldiers. What would the Seanchan do with those Children who had remained behind? Was it really the Dragon Reborn who had conquered Illian and Tear, or some false Dragon? There was talk of a gigantic stone from the sky having struck the earth far to the north in Andor, destroying an entire city and leaving a crater.

ðə tɔk əmʌŋ ðə mɛn ɹɪvil ðɛɹ wɝiz. ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv ʌndɝstʊd ðət wɝi sɝv noʊ jusfəl fʌŋkʃən. nʌn kəd noʊ ðə wivɪŋ ə ðə wil.

The talk among the men revealed their worries. They should have understood that worry served no useful function. None could know the weaving of the Wheel.

baɪɑɝz kæptɪvz tɝn aʊt tə bi ə ɡɹup ə pipəl wɪð ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə hɛvəli leɪɾən kɑɹts, pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ. ðə pipəl klʌstɝd təɡɛðɝ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ kɑɹts, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɪð hɑstɪləɾi. ɡɑləd fɹaʊnd, duɪŋ ə kwɪk ɪnspɛkʃən.

Byar's captives turned out to be a group of people with a surprisingly large number of heavily laden carts, perhaps a hundred or more. The people clustered together around their carts, regarding the Children with hostility. Galad frowned, doing a quick inspection.

"ðæts kwaɪɾ ə kæɹəvæn," bɔɹnhəl sɛd sɔfli əɾ ɪz saɪd. "mɝtʃəns?"

"That's quite a caravan," Bornhald said softly at his side. "Merchants?"

"noʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd sɔfli. "ðæts tʃɹævəl fɝnɪtʃɝ - noʊɾəs ðə pɛɡz ɑn ðə saɪdz, soʊ ðeɪ kən bi kæɹiɾ ɪn pisəz. sæks ə bɑɹli fəɹ hɔɹsəz. ðoʊz ɑɹ fɛɹiɝz tulz ɹæpt ɪn kænvəs ət ðə bæk ə ðət kɑɹt tə ðə ɹaɪt. si ðə hæmɝz pikɪŋ aʊt?"

"No," Galad said softly. "That's travel furniture - notice the pegs on the sides, so they can be carried in pieces. Sacks of barley for horses. Those are farrier's tools wrapped in canvas at the back of that cart to the right. See the hammers peeking out?"

"laɪt!" bɔɹnhəld wɪspɝd. hi sɔ ɪt tu. ðiz wɝ ðə kæmp fɑloʊɝz ʌv ən ɑɹmi ʌv səbstæntʃəl saɪz. bʌt wɛɹ wɝ ðə soʊlʒɝz?

"Light!" Bornhald whispered. He saw it too. These were the camp followers of an army of substantial size. But where were the soldiers?

"bi ɹɛɾi tə sɛpɝeɪt ðɛm," ɡɑləd toʊl bɔɹnhəld, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ. hi wɔkt ʌp tə ðə lɛd kɑɹt.

"Be ready to separate them," Galad told Bornhald, dismounting. He walked up to the lead cart.

ðə mæn dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɪt hæɾ ə θɪk fɪɡjɝ ən ə ɹʌɾi feɪs, wɪð hɛɹ ðət hæd bɪn ɝeɪnʒd ɪn ə vɛɹi pʊɹ ətɛmpt ət haɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɪnkɹisɪŋ bɔlnəs. hi nɝvəsli wɝkt ə bɹaʊn fɛl hæɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡlʌvz tʌkt ɪndə ðə bɛlt ə hɪz staʊt dʒækət. ɡɑləd kəd si noʊ wɛpənz ɑn hɪm.

The man driving it had a thick figure and a ruddy face, with hair that had been arranged in a very poor attempt at hiding his increasing baldness. He nervously worked a brown felt hat in his hands, a pair of gloves tucked into the belt of his stout jacket. Galad could see no weapons on him.

bɪsaɪd ðə kɑɹt stʊd tu ʌðɝz, mʌtʃ jʌŋɡɝ. wʌn wɑz ə bʌlki, mʌskjəlɝ taɪp wɪð ðə lʊk ʌv ə faɪɾɝ - bʌt nɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝ - hu kəd bi səm tʃɹʌbəl. ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən klʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm, baɪɾɪŋ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp.

Beside the cart stood two others, much younger. One was a bulky, muscular type with the look of a fighter - but not a soldier - who could be some trouble. A pretty woman clutched his arm, biting her lower lip.

ðə mæn ɪn ðə kɑɹt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əpɑn siɪŋ ɡɑləd. ɑ, ɡɑləd θɔt, soʊ hi noʊz ɪnʌf tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mɔɹɡeɪsəz stɛpsʌn.

The man in the cart gave a start upon seeing Galad. Ah, Galad thought, so he knows enough to recognize Morgase's stepson.

"soʊ, tʃɹævəlɝz," ɡɑləd sɛd kɛɹfəli. "maɪ mæn sɛz jə toʊld ɪm ðət jə ɑɹ mɝtʃəns?"

"So, travelers," Galad said carefully. "My man says you told him that you are merchants?"

"jɛs, ɡʊd lɔɹd," sɛd ðə dʒɹaɪvɝ.

"Yes, good Lord," said the driver.

"aɪ noʊ lɪɾəl ə ðɪs ɛɹiə. ɑɹ jə fəmɪljɝ wɪð ɪt?"

"I know little of this area. Are you familiar with it?"

"nɑt mʌtʃ, sɝ," ðə dʒɹaɪvɝ sɛd, ɹɪŋɪŋ ðət hæɾ ɪn ɪz hænz. "wi ɑɹ æktʃəli  fɑɹ fɹəm hoʊm aɪm æm bɑzəl ɡɪl, ʌv keɪɛmlɪn. aɪ hæv kʌm saʊθ sikɪŋ bɪznəs wɪð ə mɝtʃən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. bʌt ðiz ʃɔn-tʃæn ɪnveɪɾɝz əv lɛf mi əneɪbəl tə də maɪ tʃɹeɪd."

"Not much, sir," the driver said, wringing that hat in his hands. "We are actually far from home ourselves. I am Basel Gill, of Caemlyn. I have come south seeking business with a merchant in Ebou Dar. But these Sean-chan invaders have left me unable to do my trade."

hi sim vɛɹi nɝvəs. ət list i hædn laɪɾ əbaʊt wɛɹ i wɑz fɹʌm. "ænd wʌt wɑz ðɪs mɝtʃəns neɪm?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

He seemed very nervous. At least he hadn't lied about where he was from. "And what was this merchant's name?" Galad asked.

"waɪ, fælɪn dɛbɝʃə, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɪl sɛd. "ɑɹ jə fəmɪljɝ wɪð ɛbu dɑɹ?"

"Why, Falin Deborsha, my Lord," Gill said. "Are you familiar with Ebou Dar?"

"aɪ hæv bɪn ðɛɹ," ɡɑləd sɛd kɑmli. "ðɪs ɪz kwaɪɾ ə kæɹəvæn jə hæv. ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ kəlɛkʃən ʌv wɛɹz."

"I have been there," Galad said calmly. "This is quite a caravan you have. Interesting collection of wares."

"wi hæv hɝd ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ ɑɹmiz moʊbəlaɪzɪŋ hɪɹ ɪn ðə saʊθ, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ pɝtʃəs mɛni ʌv ðiz səplaɪz fɹəm ə mɝsənɛɹi tʃɹup u wɑz dɪsbændɪŋ, ən θɔɾ aɪ kəd sɛl əm daʊn hɪɹ.

"We have heard that there are armies mobilizing here in the south, my Lord. I purchased many of these supplies from a mercenary troop who was disbanding, and thought I could sell them down here.

pɝhæps jəɹ oʊn ɑɹmi hæz niɾ ə kæmp fɝnɪtʃɝ? wɪv tɛns, moʊbəl smɪθi ɪkwɪpmənt, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət soʊlʒɝz kəd juz."

Perhaps your own army has need of camp furniture? We have tents, mobile smithy equipment, everything that soldiers could use."

klɛvɝ, ɡɑləd θɔt. ɡɑləd maɪɾ əv æksɛptɪd ðə laɪ, bʌt ðə "mɝtʃənt" hæd tu mɛni kʊks, wɑʃwɪmən, ən fɛɹiɝz wɪð hɪm, ən nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf ɡɑɹdz fəɹ soʊ væljəbəl ə kæɹəvæn.

Clever, Galad thought. Galad might have accepted the lie, but the "merchant" had too many cooks, washwomen, and farriers with him, and not nearly enough guards for so valuable a caravan.

"aɪ si," ɡɑləd sɛd. "wɛl, ɪt hæpənz ðəɾ aɪ də hæv niɾ ə səplaɪz. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli fud."

"I see," Galad said. "Well, it happens that I do have need of supplies. Particularly food."

"əlæs, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə mæn sɛd. "aʊɝ fud kænɑt bi spɛɹd. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls əl sɛl, bʌt ðə fuɾ aɪ hæv pɹɑməs baɪ mɛsənʒɝ tə sʌmwʌn ɪn luɡɹd."

"Alas, my Lord," the man said. "Our food cannot be spared. Anything else I will sell, but the food I have promised by messenger to someone in Lugard."

"aɪ wɪl peɪ mɔɹ."

"I will pay more."

"aɪ meɪɾ ə pɹɑməs, maɪ ɡʊd lɔɹd," ðə mæn sɛd. "aɪ kəd nɑt bɹeɪk ɪt, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə pɹaɪs."

"I made a promise, my good Lord," the man said. "I could not break it, regardless of the price."

"aɪ si." ɡɑləd weɪv tə bɔɹnhəld. ðə soʊlʒɝ ɡeɪv kəmænz, ən tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn waɪt tɑbɝdz muv fɔɹwɝd, wɛpənz aʊt.

"I see." Galad waved to Bornhald. The soldier gave commands, and Children in white tabards moved forward, weapons out.

"wʌt . . . wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" ɡɪl æskt.

"What . . . what are you doing?" Gill asked.

"sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ jəɹ pipəl," ɡɑləd sɛd. "wil tɔk tə itʃ ə ðɛm əloʊn ən si ɪf ðɛɹ stɔɹiz mætʃ. aɪ wɝi ðət jə maɪɾ əv bɪn . . . ʌn-fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ wɪð ʌs. æftɝ ɔl, wʌɾ ɪt simz laɪk tə mi ɪz ðət jə ɑɹ ðə kæmp fɑloʊɝz ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ ɑɹmi. ɪf ðəɾ ɪz ðə keɪs, ðən aɪ wəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk tə noʊ huz ɑɹmi ɪɾ ɪz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən wɛɹ ɪɾ ɪz."

"Separating your people," Galad said. "We'll talk to each of them alone and see if their stories match. I worry that you might have been . . . un-forthcoming with us. After all, what it seems like to me is that you are the camp followers of a large army. If that is the case, then I would very much like to know whose army it is, not to mention where it is."

ɡɪlz fɔɹhɛd stɑɹɾəd tə swɛɾ əz ɡɑlədz soʊlʒɝz ɪfɪʃənli sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə kæptɪvz. ɡɑləd weɪɾəd fəɹ ə taɪm wɑtʃɪŋ ɡɪl. ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɔɹnhəld ən baɪɑɝ keɪm dʒɑɡɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm, hænz ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɹdz.

Gill's forehead started to sweat as Galad's soldiers efficiently separated the captives. Galad waited for a time watching Gill. Eventually Bornhald and Byar came jogging up to him, hands on their swords.

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," bɔɹnhəl sɛɾ ɝdʒənli.

"My Lord Captain Commander," Bornhald said urgently.

ɡɑləd tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ɡɪl. "jɛs?"

Galad turned away from Gill. "Yes?"

"wi meɪ hæv ə sɪtʃueɪʃən hɪɹ," bɔɹnhəl sɛd. hɪz feɪs wɑz flʌʃt wɪð æŋɡɝ. bɪsaɪd hɪm, baɪɑɝz aɪz wɝ waɪd, ɔlmoʊs fɹɛnzid. "sʌm ə ðə pɹɪznɝz əv tɔkt. ɪts əz jə fɪɹd. ə lɑɹdʒ ɑɹmi ɪz nɪɹbaɪ. ðeɪv skɝmɪʃt wɪð il - ðoʊz fɛloʊz oʊvɝ ðəɹ ɪn ðə waɪt ɹoʊbz ɑɹ æktʃəli  il ðɛmsɛlvz."

"We may have a situation here," Bornhald said. His face was flushed with anger. Beside him, Byar's eyes were wide, almost frenzied. "Some of the prisoners have talked. It's as you feared. A large army is nearby. They've skirmished with Aiel - those fellows over there in the white robes are actually Aiel themselves."

"ænd?"

"And?"

baɪɑɝ spæt tə ðə saɪd. "hæv jə ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə mæn kɔl pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz?"

Byar spat to the side. "Have you ever heard of a man called Perrin Goldeneyes?"

"noʊ. ʃəɾ aɪ hæv?"

"No. Should I have?"

"jɛs," bɔɹnhəl sɛd. "hi kɪl maɪ fɑðɝ."

"Yes," Bornhald said. "He killed my father."


tʃæptɝ faɪv


CHAPTER 5

ɹaɪɾɪŋz


Writings

ɡɔɪn heɪsən daʊn ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, buɾɪd fit θʌmpɪŋ ɑn ə dip blu ɹʌɡ ətɑp kɹɪmzən ən waɪt flɔɹ taɪlz. mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps ɹəflɛktəd laɪt, itʃ laɪk ə sɛntʃɹi əlɔŋ ðə weɪ.

Gawyn hastened down the hallways of the White Tower, booted feet thumping on a deep blue rug atop crimson and white floor tiles. Mirrored stand-lamps reflected light, each like a sentry along the way.

slit wɔkt kwɪkli bɪsaɪd hɪm. dɪspaɪt ðə læmps' ɪluməneɪʃən, slits feɪs sim hæf- ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn ʃædoʊ. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ðə tu-deɪ stʌbəl ɑn ɪz dʒɔ - ən ɑɾəti fəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ - əɹ ðə lɔŋ hɛɹ, klin bʌɾ ənʃɹn. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɪz fitʃɝz. ənivən, laɪk ən ənfɪnɪʃt dʒɹɔɪŋ, wɪð ʃɑɹp laɪnz, ə klft ɪn ɪz tʃɪn, ə hʊk tə hɪz wʌns-bɹoʊkən noʊz, tʃikboʊnz ðət dʒʌɾɪd aʊt.

Sleete walked quickly beside him. Despite the lamps' illumination, Sleete's face seemed half- shrouded in shadow. Perhaps it was the two-day stubble on his jaw - an oddity for a Warder - or the long hair, clean but unshorn. Or maybe it was his features. Uneven, like an unfinished drawing, with sharp lines, a cleft in his chin, a hook to his once-broken nose, cheekbones that jutted out.

hi hæd ðə laɪð moʊʃənz ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ, bʌt wɪð ə mɔɹ pɹaɪməl fil ðən moʊst. ɹæðɝ ðən ðə hʌnsmən muvɪŋ θɹu ðə wʊdz, hi wɑz ðə saɪlənt, ʃædoʊ-baʊn pɹɛɾətɝ ðət pɹeɪ nɛvɝ sɔ əntɪl ðə tiθ wɝ flæʃɪŋ.

He had the lithe motions of a Warder, but with a more primal feel than most. Rather than the huntsman moving through the woods, he was the silent, shadow-bound predator that prey never saw until the teeth were flashing.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ən ɪntɝsɛkʃən wɛɹ sɛvɹəl ə tʃʌbnz ɡɑɹdz stʊd wɑtʃ daʊn wʌn ə ðə hɔlz. ðeɪ hæd sɔɹdz ət ðɛɹ saɪdz ən wɔɹ waɪt tɑbɝdz ɛmbleɪzənd wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wʌn hɛld ʌp ə hænd.

They reached an intersection where several of Chubain's guards stood watch down one of the halls. They had swords at their sides and wore white tabards emblazoned with the Flame of Tar Valon. One held up a hand.

"aɪm əlaʊɾ ɪn," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ði æmɪɝlɪn - "

"I'm allowed in," Gawyn said. "The Amyrlin - "

"ðə sɪstɝz ɑɹən dʌn jɛt," ðə ɡɑɹd ɹɪplaɪd, hɑstəl.

"The sisters aren't done yet," the guard replied, hostile.

ɡɔɪn ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi ən slit stɛp bæk ən weɪɾəd əntɪl - faɪnəli - θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔkt aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡɑɹɾəd ɹum. ðeɪ lʊk tʃɹʌbəld.

Gawyn ground his teeth, but there was nothing to be done about it. He and Sleete stepped back and waited until - finally - three Aes Sedai Walked out of a guarded room. They looked troubled.

ðeɪ stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, fɑloʊd baɪ ə pɛɹ ə soʊlʒɝz kæɹiɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɹæpt ɪn ə waɪt klɔθ. ðə bɑɾi.

faɪnəli, ðə tu ɡɑɹdz ɹɪlʌktənli stɛpt əsaɪɾ ən lɛt ɡɔɪn ən slit pæs. ðeɪ hɝid daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ ən ɛntɝɾ ə smɔl ɹɛɾɪŋ ɹum. ɡɔɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. hi kəd si səm æksɛptɪd pikɪŋ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ, wɪspɝɪŋ.

Finally, the two guards reluctantly stepped aside and let Gawyn and Sleete pass. They hurried down the hallway and entered a small reading room. Gawyn hesitated beside the door, glancing back down the hallway. He could see some Accepted peeking around a corner, whispering.

ðɪs mɝɾɝ meɪd fɔɹ sɪstɝz kɪld. ɛɡwin hæɾ əɹ hænz fʊl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ði ədʒəz fɹəm tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹʌst ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ. ʃid wɔɹn ɛvɹiwʌn tə bi əlɝt, ən toʊl sɪstɝz nɑt tə ɡoʊ əbaʊɾ əloʊn. ðə blæk ədʒɑ nu ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɛl, ðɛɹ mɛmbɝz hævɪŋ lɪv hɪɹ fəɹ jɪɹz. wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz, ðeɪ kəd slɪp ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪz ən kəmɪt mɝɾɝ.

This murder made four sisters killed. Egwene had her hands full trying to keep the Ajahs from turning back to their mistrust of one another. She'd warned everyone to be alert, and told sisters not to go about alone. The Black Ajah knew the White Tower well, their members having lived here for years. With gateways, they could slip into the hallways and commit murder.

ət list, ðət wɑz ði əfɪʃəl ɛkspləneɪʃən fəɹ ðə dɛθs. ɡɔɪn wɑzn soʊ sɝɾən. hi dʌkt ɪndə ðə ɹum, slit fɑloʊɪŋ.

At least, that was the official explanation for the deaths. Gawyn wasn't so certain. He ducked into the room, Sleete following.

tʃʌbn hɪmsɛlf wɑz ðɛɹ. ðə hænsəm mæn ɡlænst ət ɡɔɪn, lɪps tɝnɪŋ daʊn. "lɔɹd tʃɹəkənd."

"Captain," Gawyn replied, surveying the room. It was about three paces square, with a single desk set against the far wall and an unlit coal-burning brazier. A bronze stand-lamp burned in the corner, and a circular rug nearly filled nearly the entire floor. That rug was stained with a dark liquid beneath the desk.

"du jə ɹɪli θɪŋk jəl faɪn ɛniθɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz dɪd nɑt, tʃɹəkənd?" tʃʌbn æskt, foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz.

tʃʌbn snɪft, ðən wɔkt ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd wəd wɑtʃ oʊvɝ ði ɛɹiə əntɪl sɝvəns hæd kʌm tə klin ɪt. ɡɔɪn hæɾ ə fju mɪnəts.

slit stɛpt ʌp tə wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ. ðeɪ wɝn əz æntæɡənɪstɪk təwɔɹɾ ɪm əz ðeɪ tɛndəd tə bi təwɔɹd ɡɔɪn. hi stɪl hædn fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt waɪ ðeɪ wɝ laɪk ðət wɪð hɪm.

Sleete stepped up to one of the guards just inside the doorway. They weren't as antagonistic toward him as they tended to be toward Gawyn. He still hadn't figured out why they were like that with him.

"ʃi wɑz əloʊn?" sliɾ æsk ðə mæn ɪn ɪz ɡɹævəli vɔɪs.

ɡɔɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz i kəntɪnjud tə kɹɔl əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə ɹʌɡ. fɔɹ sɪstɝz fɹəm fɔɹ dɪfɹən ədʒəz. tu hæd səpɔɹɾəd ɛɡwin, wʌn hæd səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪɾə, ən wʌn hæd bɪn nutʃɹəl, oʊnli ɹisənli ɹɪtɝnd. ɔl hæd bɪn kɪld ɑn dɪfɹən lɛvəlz ə ðə taʊɝ dʊɹɪŋ dɪfɹən taɪmz ə deɪ.

Gawyn grunted as he continued to crawl across the floor, inspecting the rug. Four sisters from four different Ajahs. Two had supported Egwene, one had supported Elaida, and one had been neutral, only recently returned. All had been killed on different levels of the Tower during different times of day.

ɪt sɝɾənli dɪd sim laɪk ðə wɝk ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ðeɪ wɝn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ spəsɪfɪk tɑɹɡəts, dʒʌs kənvən ,*nt wʌnz. bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɹɔŋ tə hɪm. waɪ nɑt tʃɹævəl ɪndə ðə sɪstɝz' kɔɹɾɝz ət naɪɾ ən kɪl əm ɪn ðɛɹ slip? waɪ dɪd noʊbɑdi sɛns tʃænəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðə wɪmən wɝ kɪld?

It certainly did seem like the work of the Black Ajah. They weren't looking for specific targets, just conven ,*nt ones. But it felt wrong to him. Why not Travel into the sisters' quarters at night and kill them in their sleep? Why did nobody sense channeling from the places where the women were killed?

sliɾ ɪnspɛktɪd ðə dɔɹ ən lɑk wɪð ə kɛɹfəl aɪ. wən ɛɡwin hæd toʊld ɡɔɪn i kəd vɪzət ðə sinz ə ðə mɝɾɝz ɪf i wɪʃt, hiɾ æskt ɪf i kəd bɹɪŋ slit wɪð hɪm. ɪn ɡɔɪnz pɹiviəs ɪntɝækʃənz wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝ, slit hæd pɹuvən hɪmsɛlf tə bi nɑɾ oʊnli mətɪkjələs, bʌt dɪskɹit.

Sleete inspected the door and lock with a careful eye. When Egwene had told Gawyn he could visit the scenes of the murders if he wished, he'd asked if he could bring Sleete with him. In Gawyn's previous interactions with the Warder, Sleete had proven himself to be not only meticulous, but discreet.

ɡɔɪn kəntɪnjud lʊkɪŋ. ɛɡwin wɑz nɝvəs əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ, hi wɑz sɝɾən. ʃi wɑzn biɪŋ kəmplitli fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ əbaʊt ðiz mɝɾɝz. hi faʊnd noʊ slɪts ɪn ðə kɑɹpəɾ əɹ taɪlz, noʊ kʌts ɪn ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ ə ðə kɹæmpt ɹum.

Gawyn continued looking. Egwene was nervous about something, he was certain. She wasn't being completely forthcoming about these murders. He found no slits in the carpet or tiles, no cuts in the furniture of the cramped room.

ɛɡwin kleɪm ðə mɝɾɝɝz wɝ kʌmɪŋ ɪn baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt hid faʊnd noʊ ɛvəɾəns ə ðæt.

Egwene claimed the murderers were coming in by gateway, but he'd found no evidence of that.

tʃɹu, hi dɪdnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ɡeɪtweɪz jɛt, ən pipəl kəd ɹɪpɔɹɾədli meɪk əm hæŋ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊn soʊ ðeɪ dɪdn kʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ. bʌt waɪ wəd ðə blæk ədʒɑ kɛɹ əbaʊt ðæt? bɪsaɪdz, ðɪs ɹum wɑz soʊ taɪni, ɪt sim tə hɪm ɪt wʊɾə bɪn vɛɹi hɑɹd tə ɡɛɾ ɪn wɪθaʊt livɪŋ səm tʃɹeɪs.

True, he didn't know much about gateways yet, and people could reportedly make them hang above the ground so they didn't cut anything. But why would the Black Ajah care about that? Besides, this room was so tiny, it seemed to him it would have been very hard to get in without leaving some trace.

"ɡɔɪn, kʌm hɪɹ," slit sɛd. ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ mæn wɑz stɪl nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ.

Gawyn joined him. Sleete threw the deadbolt a few times in its lock. "This door might have been forced," he said softly. "See the scrape here on the deadbolt? You can pop open this kind of lock by sliding a thin pick in and pushing it on the deadbolt, then putting pressure on the handle. It can be done very quietly."

"waɪ wəd ðə blæk ədʒɑ nid tə fɔɹs ə dɔɹ?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"waɪ nɑt ðən meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd?"

"ðæts tʃɹu," ɡɔɪn sɛd. hi lʊk təwɔɹd ðə blʌɾi pætʃ. ðə dɛsk wɑz sɛt soʊ ðət ði ɑkjəpəns bæk wəd bi tə ðə dɔɹweɪ. ðəɾ ɝeɪnʒmənt meɪd ɡɔɪnz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz ɪtʃ. hu wəd pʊɾ ə dɛsk laɪk ðæt? ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu θɔt ʃi wɑz kəmplitli seɪf, ən u wɑntəd tə bi sɪɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɪstʃɹækʃənz aʊtsaɪd. ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ ɔl ə ðɛɹ kʌnɪŋ, səmtaɪmz sim tə hæv ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ʌndɝɾɪvɛləpt sɛnsɪz ə sɛlf- pɹɛzɝveɪʃən.

"That's true," Gawyn said. He looked toward the bloody patch. The desk was set so that the occupant's back would be to the doorway. That arrangement made Gawyn's shoulder blades itch. Who would put a desk like that? An Aes Sedai who thought she was completely safe, and who Wanted to be sitting away from the distractions outside. Aes Sedai, for all of their cunning, sometimes seemed to have remarkably underdeveloped senses of self- preservation.

əɹ meɪbi ðeɪ dʒʌs dɪdn θɪŋk laɪk soʊlʒɝz. ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz dɛlt wɪð ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɔt. "dɪd ʃi hæv ə wɔɹɾɝ?"

Or maybe they just didn't think like soldiers. Their Warders dealt with that sort of thought. "Did she have a Warder?"

"No," Sleete said. "I've met her before. She didn't have one." He hesitated. "None of the sisters murdered had Warders."

ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv sliɾ ə ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊ.

Gawyn gave Sleete a raised eyebrow.

"meɪks sɛns," slit sɛd. "huɛvɝ ɪz duɪŋ ðə kɪlɪŋ dɪdnt wɑnə əlɝt wɔɹɾɝz."

"Makes sense," Sleete said. "Whoever is doing the killing didn't want to alert Warders."

"bʌt waɪ kɪl wɪð ə naɪf?" ɡɔɪn sɛd. ɔl fɔɹ hæd bɪn kɪl ðət weɪ. "ðə blæk ədʒɑ dʌzn əv tə oʊbeɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz. ðeɪ cʊɾə juz ðə paʊɝ tə kɪl. mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɝɛkt, mʌtʃ iziɝ."

"But why kill with a knife?" Gawyn said. All four had been killed that way. "The Black Ajah doesn't have to obey the Three Oaths. They could have used the Power to kill. Much more direct, much easier."

"bʌt ðət wəɾ ɔlsoʊ ɹɪsk əlɝɾɪŋ ðə vɪktəm əɹ ðoʊz ɝaʊnd," slit noʊɾəd.

"But that would also risk alerting the victim or those around," Sleete noted.

ənʌðɝ ɡʊd pɔɪnt. bʌt stɪl, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðiz kɪlɪŋz dɪdn sim tə æɾ ʌp.

Another good point. But still, something about these killings didn't seem to add up.

əɹ meɪbi hi wɑz dʒʌst stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ i kəd də tə hɛlp. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm θɔt ðəɾ ɪf i kəɾ eɪɾ ɛɡwin wɪð ðɪs, meɪbi ʃi wəd sɑfən təwɔɹd hɪm.

Or maybe he was just stretching at nothing, struggling to find something he could do to help. A part of him thought that if he could aid Egwene with this, maybe she would soften toward him.

pɝhæps fɝɡɪv ɪm fəɹ ɹɛskjuɪŋ əɹ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ətæk.

Perhaps forgive him for rescuing her from the Tower during the Seanchan attack.

tʃʌbn ɛntɝɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ. "aɪ tʃɹʌs jəɹ lɔɹdʃɪp əz hæd səfɪʃən taɪm," hi sɛd stɪfli.

Chubain entered a moment later. "I trust Your Lordship has had sufficient time," he said stiffly.

"ðə stæf ɪz hɪɹ tə klin."

"The staff is here to clean."

ɪnsʌfɝəbəl mæn! ɡɔɪn θɔt. dʌz i hæv tə bi soʊ dɪsmɪsɪv təwɔɹd mi? aɪ ʃəd -  noʊ. ɡɔɪn fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə kip ɪz tɛmpɝ. wʌns, ðət hædn bɪn nɪɹli soʊ hɑɹd.

Insufferable man! Gawyn thought. Does he have to be so dismissive toward me? I should -  No. Gawyn forced himself to keep his temper. Once, that hadn't been nearly so hard.

waɪ wɑz tʃʌbn soʊ hɑstəl təwɔɹd hɪm? ɡɔɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ hɪz mʌðɝ wʊɾə hændəl sətʃ ə mæn əz ðɪs. ɡɔɪn dɪdn ɔfən θɪŋk ə hɝ, əz duɪŋ soʊ bɹɔɾ ɪz maɪn bæk tə ælθɹ. ðət mɝɾɝɝ hæd bɪn əlaʊd tə wɔk əweɪ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf! ɛɡwin hæd hɛld ɪm ɪn əɹ hænd, ən hæd ɹilis hɪm.

Why was Chubain so hostile toward him? Gawyn found himself wondering how his mother would have handled such a man as this. Gawyn didn't often think of her, as doing so brought his mind back to al'Thor. That murderer had been allowed to walk away from the White Tower itself! Egwene had held him in her hand, and had released him.

tʃɹu, ælθɹ wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. bʌɾ ɪn ɪz hɑɹt, ɡɔɪn wɑntəd tə miɾ ælθɹ wɪð sɔɹɾ ɪn hæn ən ɹæm stil θɹu hɪm, dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɹ nɑt.

True, al'Thor was the Dragon Reborn. But in his heart, Gawyn wanted to meet al'Thor with sword in hand and ram steel through him, Dragon Reborn or not.

ælθɹ wəd ɹɪp jə əpɑɹt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. jəɹ biɪŋ fulɪʃ, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd. hɪz heɪtʃɹəɾ ʌv ælθɹ kəntɪnjud tə smoʊldɝ ɛniweɪ.

Al'Thor would rip you apart with the One Power, he told himself. You're being foolish, Gawyn Trakand. His hatred of al'Thor continued to smolder anyway.

wʌn ə tʃʌbnz ɡɑɹdz keɪm ʌp, spikɪŋ, pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ. tʃʌbn lʊkt ənɔɪd ðeɪ hædn faʊn ðə fɔɹs lɑk. ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd wɑz nɑɾ ə pəlisɪŋ fɔɹs - ðə sɪstɝz hæd noʊ niɾ ə ðæt, ən wɝ mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv ət ðɪs kaɪn ɑɾ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən ɛniweɪ. bʌt ɡɔɪn kəd tɛl ðət tʃʌbn wɪʃt i kəd stɑp ðə mɝɾɝz. pɹətɛktɪŋ ðə taʊɝ, ən ɪts ɑkjəpəns, wɑz pɑɹɾ ə hɪz duɾi.

One of Chubain's guards came up, speaking, pointing at the door. Chubain looked annoyed they hadn't found the forced lock. The Tower Guard was not a policing force - the sisters had no need of that, and were more effective at this kind ot investigation anyway. But Gawyn could tell that Chubain wished he could stop the murders. Protecting the Tower, and its occupants, was part of his duty.

soʊ hi ən ɡɔɪn wɝk fəɹ ðə seɪm kɑz. bʌt tʃʌbn æktəɾ əz ɪf ðɪs wɝ ə pɝsənəl kɑntɛs bɪtwin ðɛm. ðoʊ hɪz saɪd dɪd, ɪsɛnʃəli, mit dɪfit baɪ bɹaɪnz saɪɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ dɪvɪʒən, ɡɔɪn θɔt. ən əz fɑɹ əz i noʊz, aɪm wʌn ə bɹaɪnz feɪvɝd mɛn.

So he and Gawyn worked for the same cause. But Chubain acted as if this were a personal contest between them. Though his side did, essentially, meet defeat by Bryne's side in the Tower division, Gawyn thought. And as far as he knows, I'm one of Bryne's favored men.

ɡɔɪn wɑzn ə wɔɹɾɝ, jɛɾ i wɑz ə fɹɛn ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. hi daɪnd wɪð bɹaɪn. haʊ wəd ðət lʊk tə tʃʌbn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli naʊ ðət ɡɔɪn hæd bɪn ɡɪvən paʊɝ tə lʊk ɪn ɑn ðə mɝɾɝz?

Gawyn wasn't a Warder, yet he was a friend of the Amyrlin. He dined with Bryne. How would that look to Chubain, particularly now that Gawyn had been given power to look in on the murders?

laɪt! ɡɔɪn θɔɾ əz tʃʌbn ʃɑɾ ɪm ə hɑstəl ɡleɪs. hi θɪŋks aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ɪz pəzɪʃən.

Light! Gawyn thought as Chubain shot him a hostile glace. He thinks I'm trying to take his position.

hi θɪŋks aɪ wɑnə bi haɪ kæptən ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd!

He thinks I want to be High Captain of the Tower Guard!

ðə kɑnsɛpt wɑz læfəbəl. ɡɔɪn cʊɾə bɪn fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd - ʃʊɾə bɪn fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd - liɾɝ ʌv ændɝz ɑɹmiz ən pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə kwin. hi wɑz sʌn tə mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, wʌn ə ðə moʊst ɪnfluɛntʃəl ən paʊɝfəl ɹulɝz ændɝ hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. hi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ ðɪs mænz pəzɪʃən.

The concept was laughable. Gawyn could have been First Prince of the Sword - should have been First Prince of the Sword - leader of Andor's armies and protector of the Queen. He was son to Morgase Trakand, one of the most influential and powerful rulers Andor had ever known. He had no desire for this man's position.

ðət wʊdn bi haʊ ɪt lʊk tə tʃʌbn. dɪsɡɹeɪs baɪ ðə dɪstʃɹʌktɪv sintʃæn ətæk, hi mʌs fil ðəɾ ɪz pəzɪʃən wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ.

That wouldn't be how it looked to Chubain. Disgraced by the destructive Seanchan attack, he must feel that his position was in danger.

"kæptən," ɡɔɪn sɛd, "meɪ aɪ spik wɪð jə ɪn pɹaɪvət?"

"Captain," Gawyn said, "may I speak with you in private?"

tʃʌbn lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn səspɪʃəsli, ðən nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə tu ʌv əm ɹitʃɹiɾəd. nɝvəs taʊɝ sɝvəns weɪɾəd aʊtsaɪd, ɹɛɾi tə klin ðə blʌɾ əweɪ.

Chubain looked at Gawyn suspiciously, then nodded toward the hallway. The two of them retreated. Nervous Tower servants waited outside, ready to clean the blood away.

tʃʌbn foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ən ɪnspɛktɪd ɡɔɪn. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə wɪʃ ə mi, maɪ lɔɹd?"

Chubain folded his arms and inspected Gawyn. "What is it you wish of me, my Lord?"

hi ɔfən ɛmfəsaɪz ðə ɹæŋk. kɑm, ɡɔɪn θɔt. hi stɪl fɛl ðə ʃeɪm ə haʊ hid bʊliɾ ɪz weɪ ɪndə bɹaɪnz kæmp. hi wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt. lɪvɪŋ wɪð ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, ɛndʒjʊɹɪŋ ðə kənfjuʒən ən ðən ðə ʃeɪm ə ði ɪvɛns sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə taʊɝz bɹeɪkɪŋ, hæd tʃeɪnʒd hɪm. hi kʊdn kəntɪnju daʊn ðət pæθ.

He often emphasized the rank. Calm, Gawyn thought. He still felt the shame of how he'd bullied his way into Bryne's camp. He was better than that. Living with the Younglings, enduring the confusion and then the shame of the events surrounding the Tower's breaking, had changed him. He couldn't continue down that path.

"kæptən," ɡɔɪn sɛd, "aɪ əpɹiʃieɪt jə lɛɾɪŋ mi ɪnspɛk ðə ɹum."

"Captain," Gawyn said, "I appreciate you letting me inspect the room."

"aɪ dɪdn əv mʌtʃ tʃɔɪs."

"I didn't have much choice."

"aɪ ɹilaɪz ðæt. bʌt juv maɪ θæŋks nʌnðəlɛs. ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə mi ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn si mi hɛlpɪŋ. ɪf aɪ faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz mɪs, ɪt kəd min ə ɡɹeɪt dil fəɹ mi."

"I realize that. But you have my thanks nonetheless. It's important to me that the Amyrlin see me helping. If I find something the sisters miss, it could mean a great deal for me."

"jɛs," tʃʌbn sɛd, aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ. "aɪ səspɛkt ɪt kʊd."

"Yes," Chubain said, eyes narrowing. "I suspect it could."

"meɪbi ʃɪl faɪnəli hæv mi əz əɹ wɔɹɾɝ."

"Maybe she'll finally have me as her Warder."

tʃʌbn blɪŋkt. "hɝ . . . wɔɹɾɝ?"

Chubain blinked. "Her . . . Warder?"

"jɛs. wʌns, ɪt sim sɝɾən ðət ʃi wəd teɪk mi, bʌt naʊ . . . wɛl, ɪf aɪ kən hɛlp jə wɪð ðɪs ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən, pɝhæps ɪɾəl kul əɹ æŋɡɝ ət mi." hi ɹeɪzd ə hænd, ɡɹɪpɪŋ tʃʌbnz ʃoʊldɝ. "aɪ wɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ eɪd. jə kɔl mi lɔɹd, bʌt maɪ taɪɾəl ɪz ɔl bʌt minɪŋləs tə mi naʊ. ɔl aɪ wɑn ɪz tə bi ɛɡwinz wɔɹɾɝ, tə pɹətɛk hɝ."

"Yes. Once, it seemed certain that she would take me, but now . . . well, if I can help you with this investigation, perhaps it will cool her anger at me." He raised a hand, gripping Chubain's shoulder. "I will remember your aid. You call me Lord, but my title is all but meaningless to me now. All I want is to be Egwene's Warder, to protect her."

tʃʌbn ɹɪŋkəld ɪz bɹaʊ. ðən i nɑɾəd ən sim tə ɹɪlæks. "aɪ hɝd jə tɔkɪŋ. jəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mɑɹks ʌv ɡeɪtweɪz. waɪ?"

Chubain wrinkled his brow. Then he nodded and seemed to relax. "I heard you talking. You're looking for marks of gateways. Why?"

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz ðə wɝk ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪt maɪt bi ə ɡɹeɪ mæn, əɹ səm ʌðɝ kaɪndə əsæsən. eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛn əmʌŋ ðə pæləs stæf, pɝhæps? aɪ min, lʊk ət haʊ ðə wɪmən ɑɹ kɪld. naɪvz."

"I don't think this is the work of the Black Ajah," Gawyn said. "I think it might be a Gray Man, or some other kind of assassin. A Darkfriend among the palace staff, perhaps? I mean, look at how the women are killed. Knives."

tʃʌbn nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ wɝ səm saɪnz ʌv ə stʃɹʌɡəl tu. ðə sɪstɝz duɪŋ ði ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən mɛnʃən ðæt. ðə bʊks swɛp fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. ðeɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz dʌn baɪ ðə wʊmən fleɪlɪŋ əz ʃi daɪd."
