Chubain nodded. "There were some signs of a struggle too. The sisters doing the investigation mentioned that. The books swept from the table. They thought it was done by the woman flailing as she died."

"kjʊɹiəs," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ɪf aɪ wɝ ə blæk sɪstɝ, aɪd juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə fæk ðəɾ ʌðɝz maɪt sɛns ɪt. wɪmən tʃænəl ɔl ðə taɪm ɪn ðə taʊɝ; ðɪs wʊdn bi səspɪʃəs. aɪɾ ɪmoʊbəlaɪz maɪ vɪktəm wɪð wivz, kɪl əɹ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ðən ɪskeɪp bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn θɔɾ ɑdli ʌv ɪt. noʊ stʃɹʌɡəl."

"Curious," Gawyn said. "If I were a Black sister, I'd use the One Power, regardless of the fact that others might sense it. Women channel all the time in the Tower; this wouldn't be suspicious. I'd immobilize my victim with weaves, kill her with the Power, then escape before anyone thought oddly of it. No struggle."

"pɝhæps," tʃʌbn sɛd. "bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn simz kɑnfəɾənt ðət ðɪs ɪz ðə wɝk ə blæk sɪstɝz."

"Perhaps," Chubain said. "But the Amyrlin seems confident that this is the work of Black sisters."

"aɪl tɔk tə hɝ ən si waɪ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "fɔɹ naʊ, pɝhæps jə ʃəd sədʒɛs tə ðoʊz duɪŋ ði ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi waɪz tə ɪntɝvju ðə pæləs sɝvəns? ɡɪv ðɪs ɹizənɪŋ?"

"I'll talk to her and see why," Gawyn said. "For now, perhaps you should suggest to those doing the investigation that it would be wise to interview the palace servants? Give this reasoning?"

"jɛs ... aɪ θɪŋk aɪ maɪt də ðæt." ðə mæn nɑɾəd, simɪŋ lɛs θɹɛɾənd.

"Yes ... I think I might do that." The man nodded, seeming less threatened.

ðə tu stɛpt əsaɪd, tʃʌbn weɪvɪŋ ðə sɝvəns tə ɛntɝ fəɹ ðɛɹ klinɪŋ. slit keɪm aʊt, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəl. hi hɛl sʌmθɪŋ ʌp, pɪntʃt bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "blæk sɪlk," hi sɛd. "ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ ʌv noʊɪŋ ɪf ɪt keɪm fɹəm ði ətækɝ."

The two stepped aside, Chubain waving the servants to enter for their cleaning. Sleete came out, looking thoughtful. He held something up, pinched between his fingers. "Black silk," he said. "There's no way of knowing if it came from the attacker."

tʃʌbn tʊk ðə faɪbɝz. "ɑd."

Chubain took the fibers. "Odd."

"eɪ blæk sɪstɝ wʊdn sim laɪkli tə pɹoʊkleɪm hɝsɛlf baɪ wɛɹɪŋ blæk," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ə mɔɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi əsæsən, ðoʊ, maɪt nid ðə dɑɹk kʌlɝz tə haɪd."

"A Black sister wouldn't seem likely to proclaim herself by wearing black," Gawyn said. "A more ordinary assassin, though, might need the dark colors to hide."

tʃʌbn ɹæp ðə faɪbɝz ɪn ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf ən pɑkəɾɪd ðɛm. "aɪl teɪk ðiz tə sin sədaɪ."

Chubain wrapped the fibers in a handkerchief and pocketed them. "I'll take these to Seaine Sedai."

hi lʊkt ɪmpɹɛst.

He looked impressed.

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd tə slit, ən ðə tu ʌv əm ɹitʃɹiɾəd.

Gawyn nodded to Sleete, and the two of them retreated.

"ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz əbʌz ðiz deɪz wɪð ɹɪtɝnɪŋ sɪstɝz ən nu wɔɹɾɝz," slit sɛd sɔfli. "haʊ wəɾ ɛniwʌn - noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ stɛlθi -  tʃɹævəl ði ʌpɝ lɛvəlz wɛɹɪŋ blæk wɪθaʊt dʒɹɔɪŋ ətɛnʃən?"

"The White Tower is abuzz these days with returning sisters and new Warders," Sleete said softly. "How would anyone - no matter how stealthy -  travel the upper levels wearing black without drawing attention?"

"ɡɹeɪ mɛn ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi eɪbəl tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz mɔɹ pɹuf. aɪ min, ɪt simz ɑd ðət noʊbɑdi hæz æktʃəli  sin ɹiz blæk sɪstɝz. wɝ meɪkɪŋ ə lɑɾ ʌv əsʌmpʃənz."

"Gray Men are supposed to be able to avoid notice," Gawyn said. "I think this is more proof. I mean, it seems odd that nobody has actually seen rhese Black sisters. We're making a lot of assumptions."

slit nɑɾəd, aɪɪŋ ə tʃɹioʊ ʌv nɑvəsɪz u hæd ɡæðɝd tə ɡɔk ət ðə ɡɑɹdz. ðeɪ sɔ slit lʊkɪŋ ən tʃɪɾɝd tə wʌn ənʌðɝ bɪfɔɹ skæmpɝɪŋ əweɪ.

Sleete nodded, eyeing a trio of novices who had gathered to gawk at the guards. They saw Sleete looking and chittered to one another before scampering away.

"ɛɡwin noʊz mɔɹ ðən ʃiz seɪɪŋ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪl tɔk tə hɝ."

"Egwene knows more than she's saying," Gawyn said. "I'll talk to her."

"əsumɪŋ ʃɪl si ju," slit sɛd.

"Assuming she'll see you," Sleete said.

ɡɔɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. ðeɪ wɔk daʊn ə sɪɹiz ə ɹæmps tə ðə lɛvəl ə ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi.

Gawyn grunted irritably. They walked down a series of ramps to the level of the Amyrlin's study.

slit ɹɪmeɪnd wɪð ɪm - hɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ə ɡɹin neɪm hɑtɔɹi, ɹɛɹli hæd duɾiz fəɹ hɪm. ʃi stɪl hæɾ əɹ aɪz ɑn ɡɔɪn fəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ; ɛɡwin wɑz biɪŋ soʊ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ, ɡɔɪn hæd hæf ə maɪn tə lɛt hɑtɔɹi bɑn hɪm.

Sleete remained with him - his Aes Sedai, a Green named Hattori, rarely had duties for him. She still had her eyes on Gawyn for a Warder; Egwene was being so infuriating, Gawyn had half a mind to let Hattori bond him.

noʊ. noʊ, nɑt ɹɪli. hi lʌvd ɛɡwin, ðoʊ hi wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd wɪð hɝ. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn izi tə dɪsaɪd tə ɡɪv ʌp ændɝ - nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz - fəɹ hɝ. jɛt ʃi stɪl ɹəfjuz tə bɑn hɪm.

No. No, not really. He loved Egwene, though he was frustrated with her. It had not been easy to decide to give up Andor - not to mention the Younglings - for her. Yet she still refused to bond him.

hi ɹitʃt əɹ stʌɾi, ən əpɹoʊtʃt sɪlviænə. ðə wʊmən sæɾ əɾ əɹ nit, ɔɹɾɝli kipɝz dɛsk ɪn ði æntətʃæmbɝ bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwinz stʌɾi. ðə wʊmən ɪnspɛktɪd ɡɔɪn, hɝ aɪz ənɹiɾəbəl bɪhaɪn əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ mæsk. hi səspɛktəd ðət ʃi dɪdn laɪk hɪm.

He reached her study, and approached Silviana. The woman sat at her neat, orderly Keeper's desk in the antechamber before Egwene's study. The woman inspected Gawyn, her eyes unreadable behind her Aes Sedai mask. He suspected that she didn't like him.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz kəmpoʊzɪŋ ə lɛɾɝ ə səm ɪmpɔɹt," sɪlviænə sɛd. "ju meɪ weɪt."

"The Amyrlin is composing a letter of some import," Silviana said. "You may wait."

ɡɔɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ.

Gawyn opened his mouth.

"ʃi æsk nɑt tə bi ɪntɝʌptɪd," sɪlviænə sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðə peɪpɝ ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɛɾɪŋ.

"She asked not to be interrupted," Silviana said, turning back to the paper she had been reading.

"ju meɪ weɪt."

"You may wait."

ɡɔɪn saɪd, bʌt nɑɾəd. əz i dɪd soʊ, slit kɑɾ ɪz aɪ ən dʒɛstʃɝd ðəɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ.

Gawyn sighed, but nodded. As he did so, Sleete caught his eye and gestured that he was going.

waɪ hæɾ i əkʌmpənid ɡɔɪn daʊn hɪɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs? hi wɑz ən ɑd mæn. ɡɔɪn weɪv fɛɹwɛl, ən slit vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ.

Why had he accompanied Gawyn down here in the first place? He was an odd man. Gawyn waved farewell, and Sleete vanished into the hallway.

ði æntətʃæmbɝ wɑz ə ɡɹæn ɹum wɪð ə dip ɹɛd ɹʌɡ ən wʊd tʃɹɪm ɑn ðə stoʊn wɔlz. hi nu fɹəm ɪkspɪɹiəns ðət nʌn ə ðə tʃɛɹz wɝ kʌmftəɹbəl, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə sɪŋɡəl wɪndoʊ.

The antechamber was a grand room with a deep red rug and wood trim on the stone walls. He knew from experience that none of the chairs were comfortable, but there was a single window.

ɡɔɪn stɛpt ʌp tə ɪt fəɹ səm ɛɹ ən ɹɛstəɾ ɪz ɑɹm ɑn ðə ɹɪsɛst stoʊn, stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz. ðɪs haɪ ʌp, ði ɛɹ fɛl kɹɪspɝ, nuɝ.

Gawyn stepped up to it for some air and rested his arm on the recessed stone, staring out over the white Tower grounds. This high up, the air felt crisper, newer.

bɪloʊ, hi kəd si ðə nu wɔɹɾɝ pɹæktəs ɡɹaʊnz. ði oʊld wʌnz wɝ dʌɡ ʌp wɛɹ ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪɡʌn bɪldɪŋ əɹ pæləs. noʊbɑdi wɑz ʃʊɹ wʌɾ ɛɡwin wəɾ ɛn ʌp duɪŋ wɪð ðə kənstʃɹʌkʃən.

Below, he could see the new Warder practice grounds. The old ones were dug up where Elaida had begun building her palace. Nobody was sure what Egwene would end up doing with the construction.

ðə pɹæktəs ɡɹaʊnz wɝ bɪzi, ə bʌsəl ə fɪɡjɝz spɑɹɪŋ, ɹʌnɪŋ, fɛnsɪŋ. wɪð ði ɪnflʌks ə ɹɛfjudʒiz, soʊlʒɝz ən sɛl-sɔɹdz, ðəɹ wɝ mɛni hu pɹəzum ðɛmsɛlvz wɔɹɾɝ mətɪɹiəl.

The practice grounds were busy, a bustle of figures sparring, running, fencing. With the influx of refugees, soldiers and sell-swords, there were many who presumed themselves Warder material.

ɛɡwin hæɾ oʊpən ðə ɡɹaʊnz tə ɛni hu wɑntəd tə tʃɹeɪn ən tʃɹaɪ tə pɹuv ðɛmsɛlvz, əz ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə pʊʃ fəɹ əz mɛni wɪmən əz wɝ ɹɛɾi tə bi ɹeɪzd oʊvɝ ðə nɛks fju wiks.

Egwene had opened the grounds to any who wanted to train and try to prove themselves, as she intended to push for as many women as were ready to be raised over the next few weeks.

ɡɔɪn hæd spɛn ə fju deɪz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, bʌt ðə ɡoʊsts ə mɛn i hæd kɪl simd mɔɹ pɹɛzən daʊn ðɛɹ. ðə ɡɹaʊnz wɝ ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪz pæs laɪf, ə taɪm bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ. ʌðɝ jʌŋɡəlɪŋz hæɾ izəli - ən hæpəli - ɹɪtɝn tə ðət laɪf. ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɪsaʊ, ɹeɪjɹ, dɔɹən ən moʊst ə hɪz ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝz hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən əz wɔɹɾɝz. bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, nʌθɪŋ wəd ɹɪmeɪn ə hɪz bænd. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɡɔɪn hɪmsɛlf.

Gawyn had spent a few days training, but the ghosts of men he had killed seemed more present down there. The grounds were a part of his past life, a time before everything had gone wrong. Other Younglings had easily - and happily - returned to that life. Already Jisao, Rajar, Durrent and most of his other officers had been chosen as Warders. Before long, nothing would remain of his band. Except for Gawyn himself.

ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ klɪkt, fɑloʊd baɪ hʌʃt vɔɪsəz. ɡɔɪn tɝn tə faɪn ɛɡwin, dʒɹɛst ɪn ɡɹin ən jɛloʊ, wɔkɪŋ oʊvɝ tə spik wɪð sɪl-viænə. ðə kipɝ ɡlænst ət hɪm, ən i θɔɾ i kɑɾ ə tʃɹeɪs ʌv ə fɹaʊn ɑn əɹ feɪs.

The inner door clicked, followed by hushed voices. Gawyn turned to find Egwene, dressed in green and yellow, walking over to speak with Sil-viana. The Keeper glanced at him, and he thought he caught a trace of a frown on her face.

ɛɡwin sɔ hɪm. ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝin - ʃid ɡɹoʊn ɡʊɾ ət ðət soʊ kwɪkli - ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf filɪŋ ɑkwɝd.

Egwene saw him. She kept her face Aes Sedai serene - she'd grown good at that so quickly - and he found himself feeling awkward.

"ðɛɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ dɛθ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, wɔkɪŋ ʌp tə hɝ.

"There was another death this morning," he said quietly, walking up to her.

"tɛknɪkəli," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɪt wɑz læs naɪt."

"Technically," Egwene said, "it was last night."

"aɪ nid tə tɔk tə ju," ɡɔɪn blɝɾɪd.

"I need to talk to you," Gawyn blurted.

ɛɡwin ən sɪlviænə ʃɛɹɾ ə lʊk. "vɛɹi wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ bæk ɪndə hɝ stʌɾi.

Egwene and Silviana shared a look. "Very well," Egwene said, gliding back into her study.

ɡɔɪn fɑloʊd, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət ðə kipɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹændəst ɹumz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ðə wɔlz wɝ pænəld wɪð ə peɪl stʃɹaɪpt wʊd, kɑɹv tə ʃoʊ fænsɪfəl sinz, mɑɹvələsli dɪteɪld. ðə hɑɹθ wɑz mɑɹbəl, ðə flɔɹ meɪɾ ə dip ɹɛd stoʊn kʌɾ ɪndə daɪmən blɑks. ɛɡwinz lɑɹdʒ, kɑɹv dɛsk wɑz sɛt wɪð tu læmps. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə tu wɪmən ɹeɪzɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz tə ði ɛɹ, fleɪmz bɝnɪŋ bɪtwin itʃ sɛɾ ə pɑmz.

Gawyn followed, not looking at the Keeper. The Amyrlin's study was one of the grandest rooms in the Tower. The walls were paneled with a pale striped wood, carved to show fanciful scenes, marvelously detailed. The hearth was marble, the floor made of deep red stone cut into diamond blocks. Egwene's large, carved desk was set with two lamps. They were in the shape of two women raising their hands to the air, flames burning between each set of palms.

wʌn wɔl hæd bʊkkeɪsɪz fɪld wɪð bʊks ɝeɪnʒd - ɪt simd - baɪ kʌlɝ ən saɪz ɹæðɝ ðən baɪ sʌbʒɪkt. ðeɪ wɝ ɔɹnəmɛntəl, bɹɔɾ ɪn tə tʃɹɪm ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi əntɪl ɛɡwin kəd meɪk əɹ oʊn səlɛkʃənz.

One wall had bookcases filled with books arranged - it seemed - by color and size rather than by subject. They were ornamental, brought in to trim the Amyrlin's study until Egwene could make her own selections.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə faɪn soʊ nɛsəsɛɹi tə dɪskʌs?" ɛɡwin sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn əɾ əɹ dɛsk.

"What is it you find so necessary to discuss?" Egwene said, sitting down at her desk.

"ðə mɝɾɝz," ɡɔɪn sɛd.

"The murders," Gawyn said.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðɛm?"

"What about them?"

ɡɔɪn ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ. "bɝn mi, ɛɡwin. juv tə ʃoʊ mi ði æmɪɝlɪn ɛvɹi taɪm wi spik? wʌns ɪn ə waɪl, kæn aɪ si ɛɡwin?"

Gawyn shut the door. "Burn me, Egwene. Do you have to show me the Amyrlin every time we speak? Once in a while, can't I see Egwene?"

"aɪ ʃoʊ jə ði æmɪɝlɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd, "bɪkɔz jə ɹəfjuz tə æksɛp hɝ. wʌns jə də soʊ, pɝhæps wi kən muv bɪɑn ðæt."

"I show you the Amyrlin," Egwene said, "because you refuse to accept her. Once you do so, perhaps we can move beyond that."

"laɪt! juv lɝn tə tɔk laɪk wʌn ə ðɛm."

"Light! You've learned to talk like one of them."

"ðæts kəz aɪm wʌn ə ðɛm," ʃi sɛd. "jɔɹ tʃɔɪs ʌv wɝdz bɪtʃɹeɪz ju. ði æmɪɝlɪn kænɑt bi sɝv baɪ ðoʊz u ɹəfjuz tə si hɝ əθɔɹəɾi."

"That's because I am one of them," she said. "Your choice of words betrays you. The Amyrlin cannot be served by those who refuse to see her authority."

"aɪ æksɛp ju," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ du, ɛɡwin. bʌɾ ɪzən ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hæv pipəl u noʊ jə fəɹ jɝsɛlf ən nɑt ðə taɪɾəl?"

"I accept you," Gawyn said. "I do, Egwene. But isn't it important to have people who know you for yourself and not the title?"

"soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ noʊ ðət ðəɹ ɪz ə pleɪs fəɹ oʊbiɾiəns." hɝ feɪs sɔfənd. "ju ɑɹən ɹɛɾi jɛt, ɡɔɪn. aɪm sɑɹi."

"So long as they know that there is a place for obedience." Her face softened. "You aren't ready yet, Gawyn. I'm sorry."

hi sɛɾ ɪz dʒɔ. doʊn oʊvɝɹiækt, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. "vɛɹi wɛl. ðɛn, əbaʊt ði əsæsəneɪʃənz.

He set his jaw. Don't overreact, he told himself. "Very well. Then, about the assassinations.

wiv ɹilaɪz ðət nʌn ə ðə wɪmən kɪl hæd wɔɹɾɝz."

We've realized that none of the women killed had Warders."

"jɛs, aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən ə ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Yes, I was given a report on that," Egwene said.

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs," hi sɛd, "ɪt bɹɪŋz maɪ θɔts tə ə lɑɹdʒɝ ɪʃu. wi doʊn əv ɪnʌf wɔɹɾɝz."

"Regardless," he said, "it brings my thoughts to a larger issue. We don't have enough Warders."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd.

Egwene frowned.

"wɝ pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl, ɛɡwin," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "æn jɛt ðəɹ ɑɹ sɪstɝz wɪθaʊt wɔɹɾɝz. ə lɑɾ ə sɪstɝz. səm hæd wʌn, bʌt nɛvɝ tʊk ənʌðɝ æftɝ i daɪd. ʌðɝz nɛvɝ wɑntəd wʌn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə kən əfɔɹd ðɪs."

"We're preparing for the Last Battle, Egwene," Gawyn said. "And yet there are sisters without Warders. A lot of sisters. Some had one, but never took another after he died. Others never wanted one in the first place. I don't think you can afford this."

"wʌt wəd juv mi du?" ʃi sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "kəmæn ðə wɪmən tə teɪk wɔɹɾɝz?"

"What would you have me do?" she said, folding her arms. "Command the women to take Warders?"

"jɛs."

"Yes."

ʃi læft. "ɡɔɪn, ði æmɪɝlɪn dʌzn əv ðət kaɪndə paʊɝ."

She laughed. "Gawyn, the Amyrlin doesn't have that kind of power."

"ðɛn ɡɛt ðə hɔl tə də ɪt."

"Then get the Hall to do it."

"ju doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ seɪɪŋ. ðə tʃuzɪŋ ən kipɪŋ ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ ɪz ə vɛɹi pɝsənəl ən ɪntəmət dɪsɪʒən. noʊ wʊmən ʃəd bi fɔɹs tə ɪt."

"You don't know what you're saying. The choosing and keeping of a Warder is a very personal and intimate decision. No woman should be forced to it."

"wɛl," ɡɔɪn sɛd, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə bi ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd, "ðə tʃɔɪs tə ɡoʊ tə wɔɹ ɪz vɛɹi 'pɝsənəl' ən 'ɪntəmət' əz wɛl - jɛɾ ɔl əkɹɔs ðə lænd, mɛn ɑɹ kɔld ɪndə ɪt. səmtaɪmz, filɪŋz ɑɹən əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz sɝvaɪvəl.

"Well," Gawyn said, refusing to be intimidated, "the choice to go to war is very 'personal' and 'intimate' as well - yet all across the land, men are called into it. Sometimes, feelings aren't as important as survival.

"wɔɹɾɝz kip sɪstɝz əlaɪv, ən ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz gɑnə bi ʌv vaɪɾəl ɪmpɔɹɾəns sun. ðəɹ wɪl bi lidʒənz əpɑn lidʒənz ə tʃɹɑləks. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ɑn ðə fild wɪl bi mɔɹ væljəbəl ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd soʊlʒɝz, ən ɛvɹi sɪstɝ hilɪŋ wɪl bi eɪbəl tə seɪv dʌzənz ə lɪvz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ æsɛts ðət bɪlɔŋ tə hjumænɪɾi. jə kænɑɾ əfɔɹd tə lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ əbaʊɾ ʌnpɹətɛktɪd."

"Warders keep sisters alive, and every Aes Sedai is going to be of vital importance soon. There will be legions upon legions of Trollocs. Every sister on the field will be more valuable than a hundred soldiers, and every sister Healing will be able to save dozens of lives. The Aes Sedai are assets that belong to humanity. You cannot afford to let them go about unprotected."

ɛɡwin dʒɹu bæk, pɝhæps ət ðə fɝvɝ ə hɪz wɝdz. ðɛn, ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli, ʃi nɑɾəd. "pɝhæps ðəɹ ɪz . . . wɪzdəm ɪn ðoʊz wɝdz, ɡɔɪn."

Egwene drew back, perhaps at the fervor of his words. Then, unexpectedly, she nodded. "Perhaps there is . . . wisdom in those words, Gawyn."

"bɹɪŋ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "æɾ ɪts kɔɹ, ɛɡwin, ə sɪstɝ nɑt bɑndɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ ɪz ən ækt ə sɛlfɪʃnəs. ðət bɑn meɪks ə mæn ə bɛɾɝ soʊlʒɝ, ən wɪl niɾ ɛvɹi ɛdʒ wi kən faɪnd.

"Bring it before the Hall," Gawyn said. "At its core, Egwene, a sister not bonding a Warder is an act of selfishness. That bond makes a man a better soldier, and we'll need every edge we can find.

ðɪs wɪl ɔlsoʊ hɛlp pɹɪvɛn ðə mɝɾɝz."

This will also help prevent the murders."

"aɪ wɪl si wʌt kən bi dʌn," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"I will see what can be done," Egwene said.

"kʊd jə lemi si ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ðə sɪstɝz ɑɹ ɡɪvɪŋ?" ɡɔɪn sɛd, "əbaʊt ðə mɝɾɝz, aɪ min?"

"Could you let me see the reports the sisters are giving?" Gawyn said, "About the murders, I mean?"

"ɡɔɪn," ʃi sɛd, "aɪv əlaʊd jə tə bi ə pɑɹɾ ə ði ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən kəz aɪ θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi ɡʊd tə hæv ə dɪfɹən sɛɾ ʌv aɪz lʊkɪŋ θɪŋz oʊvɝ. ɡɪvɪŋ jə ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts wəd dʒʌst ɪnfluəns jə tə dʒɹɔ ðə seɪm kənkluʒənz əz ðeɪ du."

"Gawyn," she said, "I've allowed you to be a part of the investigation because I thought it might be good to have a different set of eyes looking things over. Giving you their reports would just influence you to draw the same conclusions as they do."

"æt lis tɛl mi ðɪs," hi sɛd. "hæv ðə sɪstɝz ɹeɪz ðə wɝi ðət ðɪs maɪt nɑt bi ðə wɝk ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ? ðət ði əsæsən maɪt bi ə ɡɹeɪ mæn əɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd?"

"At least tell me this," he said. "Have the sisters raised the worry that this might not be the work of the Black Ajah? That the assassin might be a Gray Man or a Darkfriend?"

"noʊ, ðeɪv nɑt," ɛɡwin sɛd, "bɪkɔz wi noʊ ðət ði əsæsən ɪz nɑt wʌn ə ðoʊz tu."

"No, they have not," Egwene said, "because we know that the assassin is not one of those two."

"bʌt ðə dɔɹ læs naɪt, ɪt wɑz fɔɹst. ən ðə wɪmən ɑɹ kɪld wɪð naɪvz, nɑt ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

"But the door last night, it was forced. And the women are killed with knives, not the One Power.

ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ saɪnz ʌv ɡeɪtweɪz əɹ - "

There are no signs of gateways or - "

"ðə kɪlɝ əz æksɛs tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, spikɪŋ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli. "æn pɝhæps ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt juzɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz."

"The killer has access to the One Power," Egwene said, speaking very carefully. "And perhaps they are not using gateways."

ɡɔɪn nɛɹoʊɾ ɪz aɪz. ðoʊz saʊndəd laɪk ðə wɝdz ʌv ə wʊmən stɛpɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ oʊθ nɑt tə laɪ. "jɔɹ kipɪŋ sikɹəts," hi sɛd. "nɑt dʒʌs fɹəm mi. fɹəm ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ."

Gawyn narrowed his eyes. Those sounded like the words of a woman stepping around her oath not to lie. "You're keeping secrets," he said. "Not just from me. From the entire Tower."

"sikɹəts ɑɹ niɾəd səmtaɪmz, ɡɔɪn."

"Secrets are needed sometimes, Gawyn."

"kæn jə tʃɹʌs mi wɪð ðɛm?" hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪm wɝid ðət ði əsæsən wɪl kʌm fəɹ ju, ɛɡwin. jə doʊn əv ə wɔɹɾɝ."

"Can't you trust me with them?" He hesitated. "I'm worried that the assassin will come for you, Egwene. You don't have a Warder."

"əndaʊɾɪdli ʃɪl kʌm fəɹ mi, ɪvɛntʃəwəli." ʃi tɔɪd wɪð sʌmθɪŋ ɑn əɹ dɛsk. ɪt lʊk laɪk ə wɔɹn lɛðɝ stʃɹæp, ðə taɪp juz tə pʌnɪʃ ə kɹɪmənəl. ɑd.

"Undoubtedly she will come for me, eventually." She toyed with something on her desk. It looked like a worn leather strap, the type used to punish a criminal. Odd.

ʃi? "pliz, ɛɡwin," hi sɛd. "wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?"

She? "Please, Egwene," he said. "What's going on?"

ʃi stʌɾid hɪm, ðən ʃi saɪd. "vɛɹi wɛl. aɪv toʊl ðɪs tə ðə wɪmən duɪŋ ði ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən.

She studied him, then she sighed. "Very well. I've told this to the women doing the investigation.

pɝhæps aɪ ʃəd tɛl jə tu. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

Perhaps I should tell you too. One of the Forsaken is in the White Tower."

hi loʊɝɾ ɪz hæn tə hɪz sɔɹd. "wʌt? wɛɹ! juv əɹ kæptɪv?"

He lowered his hand to his sword. "What? Where! You have her captive?"

"noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ʃiz ði əsæsən."

"No," Egwene said. "She's the assassin."

"ju noʊ ðɪs?"

"You know this?"

"aɪ noʊ mɛsænə ɪz hɪɹ; aɪv dʒɹim ðəɾ ɪts tʃɹu. ʃi haɪdz əmʌŋ ʌs. naʊ, fɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, dɛd? ɪts hɝ, ɡɔɪn. ɪts ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət meɪks sɛns."

"I know Mesaana is here; I've dreamed that it is true. She hides among us. Now, four Aes Sedai, dead? It's her, Gawyn. It's the only thing that makes sense."

hi bɪɾ ɔf kwɛstʃənz. hi nu vɛɹi lɪɾəl ə dʒɹimɪŋ, bʌt nu ʃi hæd ðə tælənt. ɪt wɑz sɛd tə bi laɪk fɔɹtɛlɪŋ.

He bit off questions. He knew very little of Dreaming, but knew she had the Talent. It was said to be like Foretelling.

"aɪ hævən toʊl ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud. "aɪ wɝi ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ nu wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz ɝaʊn əm ɪz sikɹɪtli wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ɪt wəd dɪvaɪɾ əs ɔl əɡɛn, əz ʌndɝ ɪleɪɾə. wiɾ ɔl bi səspɪʃəs ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ.

"I haven't told the entire Tower," Egwene continued. "I worry that if they knew one of the sisters around them is secretly one of the Forsaken, it would divide us all again, as under Elaida. We'd all be suspicious of one another.

"ɪts bæɾ ɪnʌf naʊ, wɪð əm θɪŋkɪŋ blæk sɪstɝz ɑɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn tə kəmɪt mɝɾɝz, bʌɾ ət lis ðət dʌzn meɪk əm səspɪʃəs ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ. ən meɪbi mɛsænə wɪl θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪm nɑɾ əwɛɹ ɪts hɝ. bʌt ðɛɹ, ðæts ðə sikɹət jə bɛɡd tə noʊ. ɪts nɑɾ ə blæk sɪstɝ wi hʌnt, bʌt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən."

"It's bad enough now, with them thinking Black sisters are Traveling in to commit murders, but at least that doesn't make them suspicious of one another. And maybe Mesaana will think that I'm not aware it is her. But there, that's the secret you begged to know. It's not a Black sister we hunt, but one of the Forsaken."

ɪt wɑz dɔntɪŋ tə kənsɪɾɝ - bʌt noʊ mɔɹ soʊ ðən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɔkɪŋ ðə lænd. laɪt, ə fɔɹseɪkən ɪn ðə taʊɝ simd mɔɹ plɔzəbəl ðən ɛɡwin biɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit! "wil dil wɪð ɪt," hi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ fɑɹ mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt ðən i fɛlt.

It was daunting to consider - but no more so than the Dragon Reborn walking the land. Light, a Forsaken in the Tower seemed more plausible than Egwene being the Amyrlin Seat! "We'll deal with it," he said, sounding far more confident than he felt.

"aɪ hæv sɪstɝz sɝtʃɪŋ ðə hɪstɝiz ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə taʊɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn ʌðɝz ɑɹ wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ səspɪʃəs wɝdz əɹ ækʃənz. wɪl faɪn hɝ. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si haʊ wi kən meɪk ðə wɪmən ɛni mɔɹ sɪkjʊɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪnsaɪɾɪŋ ən ivən mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs pænɪk."

"I have sisters searching the histories of everyone in the Tower," Egwene said. "And others are watching for suspicious words or actions. We'll find her. But I don't see how we can make the women any more secure without inciting an even more dangerous panic."

"wɔɹɾɝz," ɡɔɪn sɛd fɝmli.

"Warders," Gawyn said firmly.

"aɪ wɪl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, ɡɔɪn. fəɹ naʊ, ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ niɾ ə ju."

"I will think on it, Gawyn. For now, there is something I need of you."

"ɪf ɪts wɪðɪn maɪ paʊɝ, ɛɡwin." hi tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd hɝ. "ju noʊ ðæt."

"If it is within my power, Egwene." He took a step toward her. "You know that."

"ɪz ðət soʊ?" ʃi æsk dʒɹaɪli. "vɛɹi wɛl. aɪ wɑn jə tə stɑp ɡɑɹɾɪŋ maɪ dɔɹ ət naɪt."

"Is that so?" she asked dryly. "Very well. I want you to stop guarding my door at night."

"wʌt? ɛɡwin, noʊ!"

"What? Egwene, no!"

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ju si? jəɹ fɝst ɹiækʃən ɪz tə tʃælənʒ mi."

She shook her head. "You see? Your first reaction is to challenge me."

"ɪɾ ɪz ðə duɾi ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ tə ɔfɝ tʃælənʒ, ɪn pɹaɪvət, wɛɹ ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz kənsɝnd!"

"It is the duty of a Warder to offer challenge, in private, where his Aes Sedai is concerned!"

hæmɝ hæd tɔɾ ɪm ðæt.

Hammar had taught him that.

"ju ɑɹ nɑt maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, ɡɔɪn."

"You are not my Warder, Gawyn."

ðət bɹɔɾ ɪm ʌp ʃɔɹt.

That brought him up short.

"bɪsaɪdz," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ju kəd də lɪɾəl tə stɑp wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ðɪs bæɾəl wɪl bi fɔt baɪ sɪstɝz, ən aɪm biɪŋ vɛɹi kɛɹfəl wɪð ðə wɔɹdz aɪ sɛt. aɪ wɑn maɪ kɔɹɾɝz tə lʊk ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ.

"Besides," Egwene said, "you could do little to stop one of the Forsaken. This battle will be fought by sisters, and I am being very careful with the wards I set. I want my quarters to look inviting.

ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪz tə ətæk mi, pɝhæps aɪ kən sɝpɹaɪz əɹ wɪð ən æmbʊʃ."

If she tries to attack me, perhaps I can surprise her with an ambush."

"juz jɝsɛlf əz beɪt?" ɡɔɪn wɑz bɛɹli eɪbəl tə ɡɛt ðə wɝdz aʊt. 'ɛɡwin, ðɪs ɪz mædnəs!"

"Use yourself as bait?" Gawyn was barely able to get the words out. 'Egwene, this is madness!"

"noʊ. ɪts dɛspɝeɪʃən. ɡɔɪn, wɪmən aɪm ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ɑɹ daɪɪŋ. mɝɾɝd ɪn ðə naɪt, ɪn ə taɪm wən jə jɝsɛlf sɛd wɪl niɾ ɛvɹi wʊmən."

"No. It's desperation. Gawyn, women I am responsible for are dying. Murdered in the night, in a time when you yourself said we will need every woman."

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, fətiɡ ʃoʊd θɹu hɝ mæsk, ə wɪɹinəs ə toʊn ən ə slaɪt slʌmp tə hɝ bæk. ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, sʌɾənli simɪŋ wɔɹn.

For the first time, fatigue showed through her mask, a weariness of tone and a slight slump to her back. She folded her hands in front of her, suddenly seeming worn.

"aɪ hæv sɪstɝz ɹisɝtʃɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wi kən faɪn əbaʊt mɛsænə," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud. "ʃiz nɑɾ ə wɔɹiɝ, ɡɔɪn. ʃiz ən ədmɪnəstʃɹeɪɾɝ, ə plænɝ. ɪf aɪ kən kənfɹʌn hɝ, aɪ kən dɪfit hɝ. bʌt wi mʌs faɪn əɹ fɝst. ɪkspoʊzɪŋ maɪsɛlf ɪz oʊnli wʌn ə maɪ plænz - ən jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt, ɪts deɪnʒɝəs. bʌt maɪ pɹikɔʃənz əv bɪn ɪkstɛnsɪv."

"I have sisters researching everything we can find about Mesaana," Egwene continued. "She's not a warrior, Gawyn. She's an administrator, a planner. If I can confront her, I can defeat her. But we must find her first. Exposing myself is only one of my plans - and you are right, it is dangerous. But my precautions have been extensive."

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪɾ əɾ ɔl."

"I don't like it at all."

"jɔɹ əpɹuvəl ɪz nɑt ɹikwaɪɝd." ʃi aɪd hɪm. "ju wɪl əv tə tʃɹʌs mi."

"Your approval is not required." She eyed him. "You will have to trust me."

"aɪ də tʃɹʌs ju," hi sɛd.

"I do trust you," he said.

"ɔl aɪ æsk ɪz ðət jə ʃoʊ ɪt fəɹ wʌns."

"All I ask is that you show it for once."

ɡɔɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. ðən i baʊd tə hɝ ən lɛf ðə stʌɾi, tʃɹaɪɪŋ - ən feɪlɪŋ - tə kip ðə dɔɹ fɹəm ʃʌɾɪŋ tu hɑɹd wən i pʊld ɪt kloʊzd. sɪlviænə ɡeɪv ɪm ə dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ lʊk əz i pæs hɝ.

Gawyn gritted his teeth. Then he bowed to her and left the study, trying - and failing - to keep the door from shutting too hard when he pulled it closed. Silviana gave him a disapproving look as he passed her.

fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɡɹaʊnz dɪspaɪɾ ɪz dɪskʌmfɝt wɪð ðɛm. hi niɾəd ə wɝkaʊt wɪð ðə sɔɹd.

From there, he headed for the training grounds despite his discomfort with them. He needed a workout with the sword.

ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ saɪ, sɪɾɪŋ bæk, kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz. waɪ wɑz ɪt soʊ hɑɹd tə kip əɹ filɪŋz ɪn tʃɛk wən dilɪŋ wɪð ɡɔɪn? ʃi nɛvɝ fɛlt əz pʊɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ʃi dɪd wən spikɪŋ wɪð hɪm.

Egwene let out a long sigh, sitting back, closing her eyes. Why was it so hard to keep her feelings in check when dealing with Gawyn? She never felt as poor an Aes Sedai as she did when speaking with him.

soʊ mɛni ɪmoʊʃənz swɝld wɪðɪn hɝ, laɪk dɪfɹən kaɪnz ʌv waɪn spɪlɪŋ ən mɪksɪŋ təɡɛðɝ:

So many emotions swirled within her, like different kinds of wine spilling and mixing together:

ɹeɪdʒ əɾ ɪz stʌbɝnnəs, bɝnɪŋ dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ ɪz ɑɹmz, kənfjuʒən əɾ əɹ oʊn ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə pleɪs wʌn ə ðoʊz bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝ.

rage at his stubbornness, burning desire for his arms, confusion at her own inability to place one of those before the other.

ɡɔɪn hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv bɔɹɪŋ θɹu hɝ skɪn ən ɪndə hɝ hɑɹt. ðət pæʃən ə hɪz wɑz ɛntʃɹænsɪŋ. ʃi wɝid ðəɾ ɪf ʃi bɑndəd hɪm, ɪt wəɾ ɪnfɛk hɝ. wɑz ðət haʊ ɪt wɝkt? wʌɾ ɪt fil laɪk tə bi bɑndəd, tə sɛns ənʌðɝz ɪmoʊʃənz?

Gawyn had a way of boring through her skin and into her heart. That passion of his was entrancing. She worried that if she bonded him, it would infect her. Was that how it worked? What did it feel like to be bonded, to sense another's emotions?

ʃi wɑntəd ðət wɪð hɪm, ðə kənɛkʃən ðəɾ ʌðɝz hæd. ən ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðət ʃi hæv pipəl ʃi kəd ɹɪlaɪ əpɑn tə kɑntʃɹədɪk hɝ, ɪn pɹaɪvət. pipəl u nu hɝ əz ɛɡwin, ɹæðɝ ðən ði æmɪɝlɪn.

She wanted that with him, the connection that others had. And it was important that she have people she could rely upon to contradict her, in private. People who knew her as Egwene, rather than the Amyrlin.

bʌt ɡɔɪn wɑz tu lus, tu əntʃɹʌstɪŋ, jɛt.

But Gawyn was too loose, too untrusting, yet.

ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ lɛɾɝ tə ðə nu kɪŋ ə tɛɹ, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðət ɹænd wɑz θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ðə silz. hɝ plæn tə stɑp ɪm wəd dɪpɛn ɑn əɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ səpɔɹt fɹəm pipəl i tʃɹʌstɪd. ʃi hæd kənflɪktɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts əbaʊt dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə. səm sɛɾ i wɑz wʌn ə ɹændz ɡɹeɪɾəst səpɔɹɾɝz, waɪl ʌðɝz kleɪmd i wɑz wʌn ə ɹændz ɡɹeɪɾəst dɪtʃɹæktɝz.

She looked over her letter to the new King of Tear, explaining that Rand was threatening to break the seals. Her plan to stop him would depend on her gathering support from people he trusted. She had conflicting reports about Darlin Sisnera. Some said he was one of Rand's greatest supporters, while others claimed he was one of Rand's greatest detractors.

ʃi sɛt ðə lɛɾɝ əsaɪd fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ðən ɹoʊt səm θɔts ɑn haʊ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə hɔl ɑn ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɪʃu. ɡɔɪn meɪɾ ən ɛksələn ɑɹɡjəmənt, ðoʊ hi wɛn tu fɑɹ ən əsum tu mʌtʃ.

She set the letter aside for the moment, then wrote some thoughts on how to approach the Hall on the Warder issue. Gawyn made an excellent argument, though he went too far and assumed too much.

meɪkɪŋ ə pli fəɹ wɪmən u hæd noʊ wɔɹɾɝz tə tʃuz wʌn, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ɔl ə ði ædvæntɪdʒɪz ən pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt haʊ ɪt kəd seɪv laɪvz ən hɛlp dɪfit ðə ʃædoʊ ðət wəd bi əpɹoʊpɹiət.

Making a plea for women who had no Warders to choose one, explaining all of the advantages and pointing out how it could save lives and help defeat the Shadow that would be appropriate.

ʃi pɔɹd hɝsɛlf səm mɪn ti fɹəm ðə pɑɾ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ dɛsk. ɑdli, ɪt hædn bɪn spɔɪlɪŋ əz ɔfən leɪtli, ən ðɪs kʌp teɪstəd kwaɪt ɡʊd. ʃi hædn toʊld ɡɔɪn ə ði ʌðɝ ɹizən ʃiɾ æskt ɪm tə liv əɹ dɔɹ ət naɪts. ʃi hæd tʃɹʌbəl slipɪŋ, noʊɪŋ i wɑz aʊt ðɛɹ, oʊnli ə fju fiɾ əweɪ. ʃi wɝid ʃid slɪp ən ɡoʊ tə hɪm.

She poured herself some mint tea from the pot on the side of her desk. Oddly, it hadn't been spoiling as often lately, and this cup tasted quite good. She hadn't told Gawyn of the other reason she'd asked him to leave her door at nights. She had trouble sleeping, knowing he was out there, only a few feet away. She worried she'd slip and go to him.

sɪlviænəz stʃɹæp hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə bɹeɪk əɹ wɪl, bʌt ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd ... hi wɑz kʌmɪŋ deɪnʒɝəsli kloʊs tə duɪŋ soʊ.

Silviana's strap had never been able to break her will, but Gawyn Trakand ... he was coming dangerously close to doing so.

ɡɹeɪndəl æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ðə mɛsənʒɝz ɝaɪvəl. ivən hɪɹ, ɪn əɹ moʊst sikɹəɾ ə haɪɾɪŋ pleɪsəz, hɪz ɝaɪvəl wɑz nɑɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. ðə tʃoʊzən kəd nɑt haɪd fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd.

Graendal anticipated the messenger's arrival. Even here, in her most secret of hiding places, his arrival was not unexpected. The Chosen could not hide from the Great Lord.

ðə haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə pæləs, ə faɪn lɑdʒ əɹ ən eɪntʃən fɔɹtʃɹəs. ɪt wɑz ə kævɝn ɑn ən aɪlənd noʊbɑdi kɛɹɾ əbaʊt, ɪn ən ɛɹiə ʌv ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən ðət noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ vɪzəɾəd. soʊ fɑɹ əz ʃi nu, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ə noʊɾ əɹ ɪntʃɹəst ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ.

The hiding place was not a palace, a fine lodge or an ancient fortress. It was a cavern on an island nobody cared about, in an area of the Aryth Ocean that nobody ever visited. So far as she knew, there was nothing of note or interest anywhere near.

ði əkɑmədeɪʃənz wɝ daʊnɹaɪt dʒɹɛdfəl. sɪks ə hɝ lɛsɝ pɛts kɛɹd fəɹ ðə pleɪs, wɪtʃ wɑz mɪɹli θɹi tʃeɪmbɝz. ʃid kʌvɝɾ oʊvɝ ði ɛntʃɹəns wɪð stoʊn, ən ði oʊnli weɪ ɪn əɹ aʊt wɑz baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ. fɹɛʃ wɔɾɝ keɪm fɹəm ə nætʃɹəl spɹɪŋ, fud fɹəm stɔɹz ʃid bɹɔɾ ɪn pɹiviəsli, ən ɛɹ θɹu kɹæks. ɪt wɑz dæŋk, ən ɪt wɑz loʊli.

The accommodations were downright dreadful. Six of her lesser pets cared for the place, which was merely three chambers. She'd covered over the entrance with stone, and the only way in or out was by gateway. Fresh water came from a natural spring, food from stores she'd brought in previously, and air through cracks. It was dank, and it was lowly.

ɪn ʌðɝ wɝdz, ɪt wɑz pɹɪsaɪsli ðə sɔɹɾ ə pleɪs wɛɹ noʊbɑdi wəɾ ɪkspɛk tə faɪn hɝ.

In other words, it was precisely the sort of place where nobody would expect to find her.

ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət ɡɹeɪndəl kəd nɑt stæn ə læk ə lʌɡʒɝi. ðət wɑz tʃɹu. bʌt ðə bɛs pɑɹɾ əbaʊt biɪŋ pɹɪdɪktəbəl wɑz ðəɾ ɪɾ əlaʊd jə tə də ði ʌnɪkspɛktɪd.

Everyone knew that Graendal could not stand a lack of luxury. That was true. But the best part about being predictable was that it allowed you to do the unexpected.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, nʌn ə ðəɾ əplaɪd tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. ɡɹeɪndəl wɑtʃt ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ bɪfɔɹ əɹ əz ʃi ɹɪlækst ɑn ə ʃeɪz ə jɛloʊ ən blu sɪlk. ðə mɛsənʒɝ wɑz ə mæn wɪð flæt fitʃɝz ən dip tæn skɪn, wɛɹɪŋ blæk ən ɹɛd. hi dɪdnt nid tə spik - hɪz pɹɛzəns wɑz ðə mɛsədʒ.

Unfortunately, none of that applied to the Great Lord. Graendal watched the open gateway before her as she relaxed on a chaise of yellow and blue silk. The messenger was a man with flat features and deep tanned skin, wearing black and red. He didn't need to speak - his presence was the message.

wʌn ə hɝ pɛts - ə bjuɾəfəl, blæk-hɛɹd wʊmən wɪð lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn aɪz u hæd wʌns bɪn ə tɛɹən haɪ leɪɾi - stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ʃi lʊk fɹaɪɾənd. ɡɹeɪndəl fɛl mʌtʃ ðə seɪm weɪ.

One of her pets - a beautiful, black-haired woman with large brown eyes who had once been a Tairen high lady - stared at the gateway, She looked frightened. Graendal felt much the same way.

ʃi kloʊz ðə wʊd-baʊn kɑpi ʌv əlaɪɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ ɪn əɹ hænz ən stʊɾ ʌp, wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs ə θɪn blæk sɪlk wɪð ɹɪbənz ə stʃɹaɪθ ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ɪt. ʃi stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, kɛɹfəl tə pɹədʒɛkt ən ɛɹ ə kɑnfəɾəns.

She closed the wood-bound copy of Alight in the Snow in her hands and stood up, wearing a dress of thin black silk with ribbons of streith running down it. She stepped through the gateway, careful to project an air of confidence.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn stʊɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz blæk stoʊn pæləs. ðə ɹum hæd noʊ fɝnɪtʃɝ;

Moridin stood inside his black stone palace. The room had no furniture;

oʊnli ðə hɑɹθ, wɪð ə faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ. ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd! ə faɪɝ, ɑn sətʃ ə wɔɹm deɪ? ʃi meɪnteɪn əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ, ən dɪd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə swɛt.

only the hearth, with a fire burning. Great Lord! A fire, on such a warm day? She maintained her composure, and did not begin to sweat.

hi tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ, ðə blæk flɛks ə sæɑ swɪmɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz. "ju noʊ waɪ aɪ hæv sʌmən ju." nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən.

He turned toward her, the black flecks of saa swimming across his eyes. "You know why I have summoned you." Not a question.

"aɪ du."

"I do."

"ɝæŋɡɝ ɪz dɛd, lɔs tə əs - ən æftɝ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd tʃɹænsməɡɹeɪɾɪd əɹ soʊl ðə læs taɪm. wʌn maɪt θɪŋk jə ɑɹ meɪkɪŋ ə hæbəɾ ə ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ, ɡɹeɪndəl."

"Aran'gar is dead, lost to us - and after the Great Lord transmigrated her soul the last time. One might think you are making a habit of this sort of thing, Graendal."

"aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, nɛbli," ʃi sɛd. kɑnfəɾəns! ʃi hæd tə sim kɑnfəɾənt.

"I live to serve, Nae'blis," she said. Confidence! She had to seem confident.

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd dʒʌs bɹifli. ɡʊd. "ʃʊɹli jə də nɑɾ ɪmplaɪ ðəɾ ɝæŋɡɝ hæd tɝn tʃɹeɪɾɝ."

He hesitated just briefly. Good. "Surely you do not imply that Aran'gar had turned traitor."

"wʌt?" ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "noʊ, ʌv kɔɹs nɑt."

"What?" Graendal said. "No, of course not."

"ðɛn haʊ ɪz wʌt jə dɪɾ ə sɝvəs?"

"Then how is what you did a service?"

ɡɹeɪndəl peɪstɪɾ ə lʊk ə kənsɝn kənfjuʒən ɑn əɹ feɪs. "waɪ, aɪ wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ ðə kəmæn aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən. æm aɪ nɑt hɪɹ tə ɹəsiv ən ækəleɪd?"

Graendal pasted a look of concerned confusion on her face. "Why, I was following the command I was given. Am I not here to receive an accolade?"

"fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "jɔɹ feɪn kənfjuʒən wɪl nɑt wɝk ɑn mi, wʊmən."

"Far from it," Moridin said dryly. "Your feigned confusion will not work on me, woman."

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt feɪnd," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd, pɹipɛɹɪŋ əɹ laɪ. "waɪl aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd tə bi pliz tə luz wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ðə ɡeɪn wɑz ɑbviəsli wɝθ ðə kɑst."

"It is not feigned," Graendal said, preparing her lie. "While I did not expect the Great Lord to be pleased to lose one of the Chosen, the gain was obviously worth the cost."

"wʌt ɡeɪn?" mɔɹaɪɾɪn snɑɹəld. "ju əlaʊd jɝsɛlf tə bi kɑɾ ʌnəwɛɹ, ən fulɪʃli lɔs ðə laɪf ʌv wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən! wi ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə ɹɪlaɪ ɑn ju, ʌv ɔl pipəl, tə əvɔɪd stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ælθɹ."

"What gain?" Moridin snarled. "You allowed yourself to be caught unaware, and foolishly lost the life of one of the Chosen! We should have been able to rely on you, of all people, to avoid stumbling over al'Thor."

hi dɪdnt noʊ ðət ʃid baʊn ɝæŋɡɝ ən lɛft əɹ tə daɪ; hi θɔt ðɪs wɑz ə mɪsteɪk. ɡʊd.

He didn't know that she'd bound Aran'gar and left her to die; he thought this was a mistake. Good.

"kɑɾ ʌnəwɛɹ?" ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ mɔɹɾəfaɪd. "aɪ nɛvɝ . . . mɔɹaɪɾɪn, haʊ kəd jə θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪd lɛɾ ɪm faɪn mi baɪ æksəɾənt!"

"Caught unaware?" she said, sounding mortified. "I never . . . Moridin, how could you think that I'd let him find me by accident!"

"ju dɪd ðɪs ɪntɛnʃənəli?"

"You did this intentionally?"

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "aɪ pɹæktəkli hæd tə liɾ ɪm baɪ ðə hæn tə nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ. luz θɝɪn nɛvɝ wɑz ɡʊɾ ət siɪŋ fæks dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz noʊz. mɔɹaɪɾɪn, doʊn jə si? haʊ wɪl luz θɝɪn ɹiæk tə wʌt hiz dʌn? dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs, ə mɪniətʃʊɹ sɪɾi ʌv ɪts oʊn, wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ʌv ɑkjəpəns? kɪlɪŋ ɪnəsəns tə ɹitʃ ɪz ɡoʊl? wɪl ðət sɪɾ izəli wɪðɪn hɪm?"

"Of course," Graendal said. "I practically had to lead him by the hand to Natrins Barrow. Lews Therin never was good at seeing facts directly in front of his nose. Moridin, don't you see? How will Lews Therin react to what he has done? Destroying an entire fortress, a miniature city of its own, with hundreds of occupants? Killing innocents to reach his goal? Will that sit easily within him?"

mɔɹaɪɾɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. noʊ, hi hæd nɑt kənsɪɾɝd ðæt. ʃi smaɪld ɪnwɝdli. tə hɪm, eɪθɹz ækʃənz wʊɾə meɪd pɝfək sɛns. ðeɪ wɝ ðə moʊs lɑdʒɪkəl, ən ðɛɹfɔɹ moʊst sɛnsəbəl, minz ʌv əkɑmplɪʃɪŋ ə ɡoʊl.

Moridin hesitated. No, he had not considered that. She smiled inwardly. To him, ai'Thor's actions would have made perfect sense. They were the most logical, and therefore most sensible, means of accomplishing a goal.

bʌɾ ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf... hɪz maɪnd wɑz fʊl ə deɪdʒɹimz əbaʊɾ ɑnɝ ən vɝtʃu. ðɪs ɪvɛnt wəd nɑt sɪɾ izəli wɪðɪn hɪm, ən spikɪŋ ə hɪm əz luz θɝɪn tə mɔɹaɪɾɪn wəd ɹiɪnfɔɹs ðæt. ðiz ækʃənz wəd tɛɹ əɾ ælθɹ, ɹɪp əɾ ɪz soʊl, læʃ ɪz hɑɹt ɹɔ ən bliɾɪŋ. hi wəɾ əv naɪtmɛɹz, wɛɹ ɪz ɡɪlt ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz laɪk ðə joʊk ʌv ə hɛvəli leɪɾən kɑɹt.

But al'Thor himself... his mind was full of daydreams about honor and virtue. This event would not sit easily within him, and speaking of him as Lews Therin to Moridin would reinforce that. These actions would tear at al'Thor, rip at his soul, lash his heart raw and bleeding. He would have nightmares, wear his guilt on his shoulders like the yoke of a heavily laden cart.

ʃi kəd veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk, teɪkɪŋ ðoʊz fɝs fju stɛps təwɔɹd ðə ʃædoʊ. hæd ʃi ɛvɝ fɛl ðət fulɪʃ peɪn? jɛs, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. nɑɾ ɔl ə ðə tʃoʊzən hæd. sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd bɪn kɝʌp tə ðə boʊn fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. bʌɾ ʌðɝz ə ðɛm hæd teɪkən dɪfɹən pæðz tə ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɪʃəml.

She could vaguely remember what it had been like, taking those first few steps toward the Shadow. Had she ever felt that foolish pain? Yes, unfortunately. Not all of the Chosen had. Semirhage had been corrupt to the bone from the start. But others of them had taken different paths to the Shadow, including Ishamael.

ʃi kəd si ðə mɛmɹiz, soʊ dɪstənt, ɪn mɔɹaɪɾɪnz aɪz. wʌns, ʃid nɑt bɪn ʃʊɹ u ðɪs mæn wɑz, bʌt naʊ ʃi wɑz. ðə feɪs wɑz dɪfɹənt, bʌt ðə soʊl ðə seɪm. jɛs, hi nu ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ælθɹ wɑz filɪŋ.

She could see the memories, so distant, in Moridin's eyes. Once, she'd not been sure who this man was, but now she was. The face was different, but the soul the same. Yes, he knew exactly what al'Thor was feeling.

"ju toʊl mi tə hɝt hɪm," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "ju toʊl mi tə bɹɪŋ ɪm æŋɡwɪʃ. ðɪs wɑz ðə bɛst weɪ. ɝæŋɡɝ hɛlp mi, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt fli wən aɪ sədʒɛstəd. ðət wʌn ɔlweɪz əz kənfɹʌntəɾ əɹ pɹɑbləmz tu əɡɹɛsɪvli. bʌɾ aɪm sɝɾən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kən faɪn ʌðɝ tulz. wi tʊk ə ɹɪsk, ən ɪt wɑz nɑt wɪθaʊt kɑst. bʌt ðə ɡeɪn . . . bɪɑn ðæt, luz θɝɪn naʊ θɪŋks aɪm dɛd. ðəɾ ɪz ə lɑɹdʒ ædvæntɪdʒ."

"You told me to hurt him," Graendal said. "You told me to bring him anguish. This was the best way. Aran'gar helped me, though she did not flee when I suggested. That one always has confronted her problems too aggressively. But I'm certain the Great Lord can find other tools. We took a risk, and it was not without cost. But the gain . . . Beyond that, Lews Therin now thinks I am dead. That is a large advantage."

ʃi smaɪld. nɑt tu mʌtʃ plɛʒɝ. mɪɹli ə lɪɾəl sæɾəsfækʃən. mɔɹi-dɪn skaʊld, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saɪd. ət nʌθɪŋ. "aɪ æm tə liv jə wɪθaʊt pʌnɪʃmənt, fəɹ naʊ," hi faɪnəli sɛd, ðoʊ hi dɪdn saʊn plizd əbaʊɾ ɪt.

She smiled. Not too much pleasure. Merely a little satisfaction. Mori-din scowled, then hesitated, glancing to the side. At nothing. "I am to leave you without punishment, for now," he finally said, though he didn't sound pleased about it.

hæd ðət bɪn ə kəmjunəkeɪʃən dɝɛkli fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd? əz fɑɹ əz ʃi nu, ɔl tʃoʊzən ɪn ðɪs eɪdʒ hæd tə ɡoʊ tə hɪm ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl tə ɹəsiv ðɛɹ ɔɹɾɝz. əɹ ət list sʌfɝ ə vɪzət fɹəm ðət hɔɹəd kɹitʃɝ ʃaɪ-dɑɹ hæɹən. naʊ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ əpɪɹd tə bi spikɪŋ tə ðə nɛbli dɝɛkli.

Had that been a communication directly from the Great Lord? As far as she knew, all Chosen in this Age had to go to him in Shayol Ghul to receive their orders. Or at least suffer a visit from that horrid creature Shai-dar Haran. Now the Great Lord appeared to be speaking to the Nae'blis directly.

ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. ən wɝisəm.

Interesting. And worrisome.

ɪt mɛn ði ɛnd wɑz vɛɹi nɪɹ. ðəɹ wəd nɑt bi mʌtʃ taɪm lɛft fəɹ pɑstʃɝɪŋ. ʃi wəd si hɝsɛlf nɛbli ən ɹul ðɪs wɝld əz əɹ oʊn wʌns ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz dʌn.

It meant the end was very near. There would not be much time left for posturing. She would see herself Nae'blis and rule this world as her own once the Last Battle was done.

"aɪ θɪŋk," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd, "ðæɾ aɪ ʃəd - "

"I think," Graendal said, "that I should - "

jə ɑɹ tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ælθɹ," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "ju ɑɹ nɑt tə bi pʌnɪʃt, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si ɹizən tə pɹeɪz jə iðɝ. jɛs, ælθɹ meɪ bi hɝt, bʌt jə stɪl bʌŋɡəl jəɹ plæn, kɔstɪŋ əs ə jusfəl tul."

You are to stay away from al'Thor," Moridin said. "You are not to be punished, but I don't see reason to praise you either. Yes, al'Thor may be hurt, but you still bungled your plan, costing us a useful tool."

ʌv kɔɹs," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd smuðli, "aɪ wɪl sɝv əz ɪt plizɪz ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪ wɑz nɑt gɑnə sədʒɛs ðəɾ aɪ muv əɡɛnst ælθɹ ɛniweɪ. hi θɪŋks mi dɛd, ən soʊ bɛs tə lɛɾ ɪm ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɪz ɪɡnɝəns waɪl aɪ wɝk ɛlswɛɹ, fəɹ naʊ."

Of course," Graendal said smoothly, "I will serve as it pleases the Great Lord. I was not going to suggest that I move against al'Thor anyway. He thinks me dead, and so best to let him remain in his ignorance while I work elsewhere, for now."

"ɛlswɛɹ?"

"Elsewhere?"

ɡɹeɪndəl niɾəd ə vɪktɝi, ə dɪsaɪsɪv wʌn. ʃi sɪftɪd θɹu ðə dɪfɹən plænz ʃid dɪvaɪzd, səlɛktɪŋ ðə moʊs laɪkli tə səksid. ʃi kʊdn muv əɡɛnst ɔltʃɹiɝ? vɛɹi wɛl. ʃi wəd bɹɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd sʌmθɪŋ hid lɔŋ dɪzaɪɝd.

Graendal needed a victory, a decisive one. She sifted through the different plans she'd devised, selecting the most likely to succeed. She couldn't move against al'Trior? Very well. She would bring to the Great Lord something he'd long desired.

"pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. ʃi fɛlt ɪkspoʊzd, hævɪŋ tə ɹɪvil əɹ ɪntɛntʃənz tə mɔɹaɪɾɪn. ʃi pɹəfɝd tə kip əɹ plɑts tə hɝsɛlf. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi daʊɾɪd ʃid bi eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp ðɪs miɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt tɛlɪŋ hɪm. "aɪ wɪl bɹɪŋ jə hɪz hɛd."

"Perrin Aybara," Graendal said. She felt exposed, having to reveal her intentions to Moridin. She preferred to keep her plots to herself. However, she doubted she'd be able to escape this meeting without telling him. "I will bring you his head."

mɔɹaɪɾɪn tɝn təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝ, klæspɪŋ ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hi wɑtʃt ðə fleɪmz.

Moridin turned toward the fire, clasping his hands behind his back. He watched the flames.

wɪð ə ʃɑk, ʃi fɛl swɛt tʃɹɪkəl daʊn əɹ bɹaʊ. wʌt? ʃi wɑz eɪbəl tə əvɔɪd hiɾ ən koʊld.

With a shock, she felt sweat trickle down her brow. What? She was able to avoid heat and cold.

wʌt wɑz ɹɔŋ? ʃi meɪnteɪn əɹ foʊkəs . . . ɪt dʒʌs dɪdnt wɝk. nɑt hɪɹ. nɑt nɪɹ hɪm.

What was wrong? She maintained her focus . . . it just didn't work. Not here. Not near him.

ðəɾ ənsɛɾəld əɹ dipli.

That unsettled her deeply.

"hiz ɪmpɔɹɾənt," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "ðə pɹɑfəsiz - "

"He's important," Graendal said. "The prophecies - "

"aɪ noʊ ðə pɹɑfəsiz," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd sɔfli. hi dɪd nɑt tɝn. "haʊ wəd jə də ɪt?"

"I know the prophecies," Moridin said softly. He did not turn. "How would you do it?"

"maɪ spaɪz əv loʊkeɪɾəd ɪz ɑɹmi," ɡɹeɪndəl sɛd. "aɪ hæv ɔlɹɛɾi sɛt səm plænz ɪn moʊʃən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ hɪm, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. aɪ ɹɪteɪn ðə ɡɹup ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ɡɪvən mi tə kɑz keɪɑs, ən aɪ hæv ə tʃɹæp pɹipɛɹd. ɪɾəl bɹeɪk ælθɹ, ɹuən hɪm, ɪf i luzəz eɪbɑɹə."

"My spies have located his army," Graendal said. "I have already set some plans in motion regarding him, just in case. I retain the group of Shadowspawn given me to cause chaos, and I have a trap prepared. It will break al'Thor, ruin him, if he loses Aybara."

"ɪt wɪl də mɔɹ ðən ðæt," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd sɔfli. "bʌt jəl nɛvɝ mænədʒ ɪt. hɪz mɛn əv ɡeɪtweɪz. hɪl ɪskeɪp ju."

"It will do more than that," Moridin said softly. "But you will never manage it. His men have gateways. He will escape you."

"hi wɪl ɪskeɪp ju," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd sɔfli.

"He will escape you," Moridin said softly.

ðə swɛt tʃɹɪkəl daʊn əɹ tʃik, ðən tə hɝ tʃɪn. ʃi waɪpt ɪt kæʒəwəli, bʌɾ əɹ bɹaʊ kəntɪnjud tə bid.

The sweat trickled down her cheek, then to her chin. She wiped it casually, but her brow continued to bead.

"kʌm," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə hɑɹθ ən təwɔɹd ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd.

"Come," Moridin said, striding from the hearth and toward the hallway outside.

ɡɹeɪndəl fɑloʊd, kjʊɹiəs bʌɾ əfɹeɪd. mɔɹaɪɾɪn lɛɾ əɹ tə ə nɪɹbaɪ dɔɹ, sɛɾ ɪn ðə seɪm blæk stoʊn wɔlz. hi pʊʃt ɪɾ oʊpən.

Graendal followed, curious but afraid. Moridin led her to a nearby door, set in the same black stone walls. He pushed it open.

ɡɹeɪndəl fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɪnsaɪd. ðə nɛɹoʊ ɹum wɑz laɪnd wɪð ʃɛlvz. ən ɑn əm wɝ dʌzənz - pɝhæps hʌnʒɹədz - ʌv ɑbʒɛkts ə paʊɝ. dɑɹknəs wɪðɪn! ʃi θɔt. wɛɹ dɪɾ i ɡɛt soʊ mɛni?

Graendal followed him inside. The narrow room was lined with shelves. And on them were dozens - perhaps hundreds - of objects of Power. Darkness within! she thought. Where did he get so many?

mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɔk tə ði ɛn ə ðə ɹum, wɛɹ i pɪk θɹu ɑbʒɛkts ɑn ə ʃɛlf. ɡɹeɪndəl ɛntɝd, ɔd. "ɪz ðəɾ ə ʃɑkləns?" ʃi æskt, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə lɔŋ θɪn bɪɾ ə mɛɾəl. "θɹi baɪndɪŋ ɹɑdz? ə ɹimɑkɹ? ðoʊz pisəz ʌv ə ʃoʊ - "

Moridin walked to the end of the room, where he picked through objects on a shelf. Graendal entered, awed. "Is that a shocklance?" she asked, pointing to a long thin bit of metal. "Three binding rods? A rema'kar? Those pieces of a sho - "

"ɪɾ ɪz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt," hi sɛd, səlɛktɪŋ ən aɪɾəm.

"It is unimportant," he said, selecting an item.

"ɪf aɪ kəd dʒʌst - "

"If I could just - "

"ju ɑɹ kloʊs tə luzɪŋ feɪvɝ, ɡɹeɪndəl," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ən hoʊldɪŋ lɔŋ, spɪklaɪk pis ə mɛɾəl, sɪlvɝi ən tɑpt wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ mɛɾəl hɛd sɛt wɪð ɡoʊldən ɪnleɪ. "aɪ hæv faʊn oʊnli tu ʌv ðiz. ði ʌðɝ ɪz biɪŋ pʊt tə ɡʊd juz. jə meɪ juz ðɪs wʌn."

"You are close to losing favor, Graendal," he said, turning and holding long, spikelike piece of metal, silvery and topped with a large metal head set with golden inlay. "I have found only two of these. The other is being put to good use. You may use this one."

"ə dʒɹimspaɪk?" ʃi sɛd, aɪz oʊpənɪŋ waɪd. haʊ bædli ʃid wɑntəd tə hæv wʌn ə ðiz!

"A dreamspike?" she said, eyes opening wide. How badly she'd wanted to have one of these!

"ju faʊn tu?"

"You found two?"

hi tæp ðə tɑp ə ðə dʒɹimspaɪk ən ɪt vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪz hænd. "ju wɪl noʊ wɛɹ tə faɪn ɪt?"

He tapped the top of the dreamspike and it vanished from his hand. "You will know where to find it?"

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd, ɡɹoʊɪŋ hʌŋɡɹi. ðɪs wɑz ən əbdʒɛkt ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ. jusfəl ɪn soʊ mɛni dɪfɹənt weɪz.

"Yes," she said, growing hungry. This was an object of great Power. Useful in so many different ways.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn stɛp fɔɹwɝd, sizɪŋ əɹ aɪz wɪð ɪz oʊn. "ɡɹeɪndəl," hi sɛd sɔfli, deɪnʒɝəsli.

Moridin stepped forward, seizing her eyes with his own. "Graendal," he said softly, dangerously.

"aɪ noʊ ðə ki fəɹ ðɪs wʌn. ɪɾəl nɑt bi juzd əɡɛns mi, əɹ ʌðɝz ə ðə tʃoʊzən. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɪl noʊ ɪf jə du. aɪ də nɑt wɪʃ jəɹ əpɛɹən hæbət tə bi ɪndʌlʒd fɝðɝ, nɑɾ əntɪl eɪbɑɹə ɪz dɛd."

"I know the key for this one. It will not be used against me, or others of the Chosen. The Great Lord will know if you do. I do not wish your apparent habit to be indulged further, not until Aybara is dead."

"aɪ. . . jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs." ʃi fɛl koʊld, sʌɾənli. haʊ kəd ʃi fil koʊl hɪɹ? ən waɪl stɪl swɛɾɪŋ?

"I. . . yes, of course." She felt cold, suddenly. How could she feel cold here? And while still sweating?

"eɪbɑɹə kən wɔk ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɪl lɛn jə ənʌðɝ tul, ðə mæn wɪð tu soʊlz. bʌt hiz maɪn, dʒʌst əz ðət spaɪk ɪz maɪn. dʒʌst əz jə ɑɹ maɪn. dʒju ʌndɝstænd?"

"Aybara can walk the World of Dreams," Moridin said. "I will lend you another tool, the man with two souls. But he is mine, just as that spike is mine. Just as you are mine. Do you understand?"

ʃi nɑɾəd. ʃi kʊdn hɛlp hɝsɛlf. ðə ɹum sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹkɝ. ðət vɔɪs ə hɪz .

She nodded. She couldn't help herself. The room seemed to be growing darker. That voice of his .

. . ɪt saʊndəd, dʒʌs feɪnli, laɪk ðəɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd.

. . it sounded, just faintly, like that of the Great Lord.

"lɛt mi tɛl jə ðɪs, haʊɛvɝ," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, ɹitʃɪŋ fɔɹwɝd wɪð ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, kʌpɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn. "ɪf jə də səksid, ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɪl bi plizd. vɛɹi plizd. ðət wɪtʃ əz bɪn ɡɹæntəd jə ɪn spɑɹsnəs wɪl bi hipt əpɑn jə ɪn ɡlɔɹi."

"Let me tell you this, however," Moridin said, reaching forward with his right hand, cupping her chin. "If you do succeed, the Great Lord will be pleased. Very pleased. That which has been granted you in sparseness will be heaped upon you in glory."

ʃi lɪkt əɹ dʒɹaɪ lɪps. ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, mɔɹaɪɾɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu dɪstənt.

She licked her dry lips. In front of her, Moridin's expression grew distant.

"mɔɹaɪɾɪn?" ʃi æsk hɛzɪɾəntli.

"Moridin?" she asked hesitantly.

hi ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ, ɹilisɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn ən wɔkɪŋ tə ði ɛn ə ðə ɹum. fɹəm ə teɪbəl, hi pɪkt ʌp ə θɪk toʊm ɹæpt ɪn peɪl tæn skɪn. hi flɪp tə ə sɝɾən peɪdʒ ən stʌɾid ɪt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ðən i weɪv fəɹ əɹ tə əpɹoʊtʃ.

He ignored her, releasing her chin and walking to the end of the room. From a table, he picked up a thick tome wrapped in pale tan skin. He flipped to a certain page and studied it for a moment. Then he waved for her to approach.

ʃi dɪd soʊ, kɛɹfəl. wən ʃi ɹɛd wʌt wɑz ɑn ðə peɪdʒ, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf stʌnd.

She did so, careful. When she read what was on the page, she found herself stunned.

dɑɹknəs wɪðɪn! "wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs bʊk?" ʃi faɪnəli mænədʒ tə fɔɹs aʊt. wɛɹ dɪd ðiz pɹɑfəsiz kʌm fɹʌm?"

Darkness within! "What is this book?" she finally managed to force out. Where did these prophecies come from?"

"ðeɪ hæv lɔŋ bɪn noʊn tə mi," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd sɔfli, stɪl stʌɾiɪŋ ðə bʊk. "bʌt nɑt tə mɛni ʌðɝz, nɑɾ ivən ðə tʃoʊzən. ðə wɪmən ən mɛn u spoʊk ðiz wɝ aɪsəleɪɾəd ən hɛld əloʊn. ðə laɪt mʌs nɛvɝ noʊ ʌv ðiz wɝdz.

"They have long been known to me," Moridin said softly, still studying the book. "But not to many others, not even the Chosen. The women and men who spoke these were isolated and held alone. The Light must never know of these words.

wi noʊ ʌv ðɛɹ pɹɑfəsiz, bʌt ðəl nɛvɝ noʊ ɔl ʌv aʊɝz."

We know of their prophecies, but they will never know all of ours."

"bʌt ðɪs . . ." ʃi sɛd, ɹiɹiɾɪŋ ðə pæsədʒ. "ðɪs sɛz eɪbɑɹə wɪl daɪ!"

"But this . . ." she said, rereading the passage. "This says Aybara will die!"

"ðɛɹ kən bi mɛni ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃənz ʌv ɛni pɹɑfəsi," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "bʌt jɛs. ðɪs fɔɹtɛlɪŋ pɹɑməsəz ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə wɪl daɪ baɪ əɹ hænd. jəl bɹɪŋ mi ðə hɛɾ ə ðɪs wʊlf, ɡɹeɪndəl. ən wən jə du, ɛniθɪŋ jə æsk ʃæl bi jʊɹz." hi slæp ðə bʊk kloʊzd. "bʌt mɑɹk mi. feɪl, ən jəl luz wʌt juv ɡeɪnd. ən mʌtʃ mɔɹ."

"There can be many interpretations of any prophecy," Moridin said. "But yes. This Foretelling promises that Aybara will die by our hand. You will bring me the head of this wolf, Graendal. And when you do, anything you ask shall be yours." He slapped the book closed. "But mark me. Fail, and you will lose what you have gained. And much more."

hi oʊpən ə pɔɹɾəl fəɹ əɹ wɪð ə weɪv ə ðə hænd; hɝ feɪn əbɪləɾi tə tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ -  ðət hædn bɪn ɹimuv fɹəm əɹ - əlaʊɾ əɹ tə si twɪstəd wivz stæb ði ɛɹ ən ɹɛn ɪt, ɹɪpɪŋ ə hoʊl ɪn ðə fæbɹɪk ə ðə pæɾɝn. ði ɛɹ ʃɪmɝd ðɛɹ. ɪt wəd lɛd bæk tə hɝ hɪɾən kævɝn, ʃi nu.

He opened a portal for her with a wave of the hand; her faint ability to touch the True Power -  that hadn't been removed from her - allowed her to see twisted weaves stab the air and rend it, ripping a hole in the fabric of the Pattern. The air shimmered there. It would lead back to her hidden cavern, she knew.

ʃi wɛn θɹu wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd. ʃi dɪdn tʃɹʌst əɹ vɔɪs tə spik wɪθaʊt ʃeɪkɪŋ.

She went through without a word. She didn't trust her voice to speak without shaking.

tʃæptɝ sɪks

CHAPTER 6

kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɪntɛntʃənz mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, wʌns kwin ʌv ændɝ, sɝv ti. ʃi muv fɹəm pɝsən tə pɝsən ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ pəvɪljən pɛɹɪn hæd teɪkən fɹəm meɪɾən. ɪt hæd saɪdz ðət kəd bi ɹoʊld ʌp ən noʊ tɛn flɔɹ.

Questioning Intentions Morgase Trakand, once Queen of Andor, served tea. She moved from person to person in the large pavilion Perrin had taken from Maiden. It had sides that could be rolled up and no tent floor.

lɑɹdʒ ðoʊ ðə tɛnt wɑz, ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɪnʌf ɹum fəɹ ɔl u hæd wɑntəd tə ətɛn ðə miɾɪŋ. pɛɹɪn ən feɪl wɝ ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nɛks tə ðɛm sæt ɡoʊldən-aɪɾ ɛlaɪəs ən tæm ælθɹ, ðə sɪmpəl fɑɹmɝ wɪð ðə bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz ən ðə kɑm mænɝz. wɑz ðɪs mæn ɹɪli ðə fɑðɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ʌv kɔɹs, mɔɹɡeɪs hæd sin ɹænd ælθɹ wʌns, ən ðə bɔɪ hædn lʊk mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ə fɑɹmɝ hɪmsɛlf.

Large though the tent was, there was barely enough room for all who had wanted to attend the meeting. Perrin and Faile were there, of course, sitting on the ground. Next to them sat golden-eyed Elyas and Tam al'Thor, the simple farmer with the broad shoulders and the calm manners. Was this man really the father of the Dragon Reborn? Of course, Morgase had seen Rand al'Thor once, and the boy hadn't looked much more than a farmer himself.

bɪsaɪd tæm sæt pɛɹɪnz dʌsti sɛkɹətɛɹi, sɛbæn beɪlwɝ. haʊ mʌtʃ dɪd pɛɹɪn noʊ ʌv ɪz pæst?

Beside Tam sat Perrin's dusty secretary, Sebban Balwer. How much did Perrin know of his past?

dʒɝ ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz ðəɹ ɔlsoʊ, wɛɹɪŋ ɪz blæk koʊt wɪð ə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd pɪn ɑn ðə kɑlɝ. hɪz lɛðɝi fɑɹmɝz feɪs wɑz hɑloʊ-aɪɾ ən stɪl peɪl fɹəm ðə sɪknəs hid sʌfɝd ɹisənli. nild - ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən - wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. hi hædn jɛt ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm ɪz sneɪkbaɪts.

Jur Grady was there also, wearing his black coat with a silver sword pin on the collar. His leathery farmer's face was hollow-eyed and still pale from the sickness he'd suffered recently. Neald - the other Asha'man - was not there. He hadn't yet recovered from his snakebites.

ɔl θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ðɛɹ. siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi sæt wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən ənʊɹə sæt bɪsaɪd bɹəleɪn, əkeɪʒənəli ʃuɾɪŋ ɡlænsɪz ət ðə sɪks waɪz wʌnz. ɡælɛn sæɾ ɑn bɹəleɪnz ʌðɝ saɪd. əkɹɔs fɹəm əm sæɾ æliændɝ ən ɑɹɡændə.

All three Aes Sedai were there. Seonid and Masuri sat with the Wise Ones, and Annoura sat beside Berelain, occasionally shooting glances at the six Wise Ones. Gallenne sat on Berelain's other side. Across from them sat Alliandre and Arganda.

ði ɔfəsɝz meɪd mɔɹɡeɪs θɪŋk ʌv ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. ʃi hædn sin ɪm ɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl, nɑt sɪns ʃiɾ ɛɡzaɪld ɪm fəɹ ɹizənz ʃi stɪl kʊdn kwaɪɾ ɪkspleɪn. vɛɹi lɪɾəl əbaʊt ðət taɪm ɪn əɹ laɪf meɪd sɛns tə hɝ naʊ. hæd ʃi ɹɪli bɪn soʊ ɪnfætʃueɪɾɪd wɪð ə mæn ðət ʃid bænɪʃt æɛmlɪn ən ɛlɹin?

The officers made Morgase think of Gareth Bryne. She hadn't seen him in a long while, not since she'd exiled him for reasons she still couldn't quite explain. Very little about that time in her life made sense to her now. Had she really been so infatuated with a man that she'd banished Aemlyn and Ellorien?

ɛniweɪ, ðoʊz deɪz wɝ ɡɔn. naʊ mɔɹɡeɪs pɪkt əɹ weɪ kɛɹfəli θɹu ðə ɹum ən sɔ ðət pipəlz kʌps wɝ kɛp fʊl.

Anyway, those days were gone. Now Morgase picked her way carefully through the room and saw that people's cups were kept full.

"jɔɹ wɝk tʊk lɔŋɡɝ ðən aɪɾ ɪkspɛktəd," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Your work took longer than I'd expected," Perrin said.

"ju ɡeɪv əs ə duɾi tə ətɛn tə, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," nəvɛɝɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "wi əkɑmplɪʃt ɪt. ɪt tʊk əs əz mʌtʃ taɪm əz niɾəd tə də ɪt kɝɛkli. ʃʊɹli jə doʊn ɪmplaɪ ðət wi dɪɾ ʌðɝwaɪz." ðə sændi- hɛɹd waɪz wʌn sæt dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi.

"You gave us a duty to attend to, Perrin Aybara," Nevarin replied. "We accomplished it. It took us as much time as needed to do it correctly. Surely you don't imply that we did otherwise." The sandy- haired Wise One sat directly in front of Seonid and Masuri.

"ɡɪv oʊvɝ, nəvɛɝɪn," pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz i ənɹoʊld ə mæp bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd; ɪt hæd bɪn dʒɹɔn baɪ beɪlwɝ juzɪŋ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fɹəm ðə ɡildænɪn. "aɪ wɑzn kwɛstʃənɪŋ ju. aɪ wɑz æskɪŋ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛni pɹɑbləmz ɪn ðə bɝnɪŋ."

"Give over, Nevarin," Perrin grunted as he unrolled a map before him on the ground; it had been drawn by Balwer using instructions from the Ghealdanin. "I wasn't questioning you. I was asking if there were any problems in the burning."

"ðə vɪlədʒ ɪz ɡɔn," nəvɛɝɪn sɛd. "æn ɛvɹi plænt wi faʊnd wɪð ə hɪn ə blaɪɾ əz bɪn bɝn tə æʃ. əz wɛl wi dɪd. jə wɛtləndɝz wəɾ əv mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl dilɪŋ wɪð sʌmθɪŋ əz dɛdli əz ðə blaɪt."

"The village is gone," Nevarin said. "And every plant we found with a hint of Blight has been burned to ash. As well we did. You wetlanders would have much trouble dealing with something as deadly as the Blight."

"aɪ θɪŋk," feɪl sɛd, "ðæt jə wəd bi sɝpɹaɪzd."

"I think," Faile said, "that you would be surprised."

mɔɹɡeɪs ɡlænst ət feɪl, hu lɑkt aɪz wɪð ðə waɪz wʌn. feɪl sæt laɪk ə kwin, wʌns əɡɛn dʒɹɛs tə hɝ steɪʃən ɪn ə faɪn dʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹin ən vaɪəlɪt, pliɾɪd daʊn ðə saɪdz ən dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ. ɑdli, vɔɪlz sɛns ə liɾɝʃɪp sim tə hæv bɪn ɛnhæns baɪ hɝ taɪm spɛnt wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ.

Morgase glanced at Faile, who locked eyes with the Wise One. Faile sat like a queen, once again dressed to her station in a fine dress of green and violet, pleated down the sides and divided for riding. Oddly, Voiles sense of leadership seemed to have been enhanced by her time spent with the Shaido.

mɔɹɡeɪs ən feɪl hæd kwɪkli ɡɔn bæk tə biɪŋ mɪstʃɹəs ən sɝvənt. ɪn fækt, mɔɹɡeɪsəz laɪf hɪɹ wɑz stʃɹaɪkɪŋli sɪməlɝ tə wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp. tʃɹu, səm θɪŋz wɝ dɪfɹənt;

Morgase and Faile had quickly gone back to being mistress and servant. In fact, Morgase's life here was strikingly similar to what it had been in the Shaido camp. True, some things were different;

mɔɹɡeɪs wɑzn laɪkli tə bi stʃɹæp hɪɹ, fəɹ ɪnstəns. ðət dɪdn tʃeɪnʒ ðə fæk ðət -  fəɹ ə taɪm -  ʃi ən ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ wɪmən hæd bɪn ikwəlz. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ.

Morgase wasn't likely to be strapped here, for instance. That didn't change the fact that -  for a time -  she and the other four women had been equals. No longer.

mɔɹɡeɪs stɑp bɪsaɪd lɔɹd ɡælɛn ən ɹifɪld ɪz kʌp, juzɪŋ ðə seɪm skɪlz ʃid kʌltəveɪɾəd ɪn ətɛndɪŋ sɪvænə. ət taɪmz, biɪŋ ə sɝvən sim tə ɹikwaɪɝ mɔɹ stɛlθ ðən biɪŋ ə skaʊt. ʃi wɑzn tə bi sin, wɑzn tə dɪstʃɹækt. hæɾ əɹ oʊn sɝvəns æktəd ðɪs weɪ ɝaʊn hɝ?

Morgase stopped beside Lord Gallenne and refilled his cup, using the same skills she'd cultivated in attending Sevanna. At times, being a servant seemed to require more stealth than being a scout. She wasn't to be seen, wasn't to distract. Had her own servants acted this way around her?

"wɛl," ɑɹɡændə sɛd, "ɪf ɛniwʌn ɪz wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ wiv ɡɔn, ðə smoʊk fɹəm ðət faɪɝ ɪz ən izi ɪndəkeɪɾɝ."

"Well," Arganda said, "if anyone is wondering where we've gone, the smoke from that fire is an easy indicator."

"wɝ fɑɹ tu mɛni pipəl tə θɪŋk ə haɪɾɪŋ," siɑnɪd sɛd. ɹisənli, ʃi ən mɑsʊɝi hæd bɪɡʌn biɪŋ əlaʊd tə spik wɪθaʊt ɹɛpɹəmæn fɹəm ðə waɪz wʌnz, ðoʊ ðə ɡɹin dɪd stɪl ɡlæns ət ði il wɪmən bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. ɪt ɡæl mɔɹɡeɪs tə si ðæt. sɪstɝz ə ðə taʊɝ, meɪɾ əpɝən- taɪsəz tə ə bʌntʃ ʌv waɪldɝz? ɪt wɑz sɛd tə hæv bɪn dʌn ət ɹænd ælθɹz ɔɹɾɝ, bʌt haʊ wəɾ ɛni mæn - ivən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - bi keɪpəbəl ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ?

"We're far too many people to think of hiding," Seonid said. Recently, she and Masuri had begun being allowed to speak without reprimand from the Wise Ones, though the Green did still glance at the Aiel women before speaking. It galled Morgase to see that. Sisters of the Tower, made appren- tices to a bunch of wilders? It was said to have been done at Rand al'Thor's order, but how would any man - even the Dragon Reborn - be capable of such a thing?

ɪt dɪskʌmfɝɾɪd əɹ ðət ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sim tə ɹɪzɪs ðɛɹ steɪʃən. ə pɝsənz sɪtʃueɪʃən ɪn laɪf kəd tʃeɪnʒ əɹ dʒɹəmæɾɪkli. ɡeɪbɹəl, ðən vɑldə, hæd tɔt mɔɹɡeɪs ðət lɛsən.

It discomforted her that the two Aes Sedai no longer seemed to resist their station. A person's situation in life could change her dramatically. Gaebril, then Valda, had taught Morgase that lesson.

ði il kæptɪvəɾi hæd bɪn mɪɹli ənʌðɝ stɛp ɪn ðə pɹɑsɛs.

The Aiel captivity had been merely another step in the process.

itʃ ə ðiz ɪkspɪɹiənsɪz hæd muvd əɹ fɑɹðɝ əweɪ fɹəm ðə kwin ʃi hæd bɪn. naʊ ʃi dɪdn lɔŋ fəɹ faɪn θɪŋz əɹ əɹ θɹoʊn. ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəd səm stəbɪlɪɾi. ðæt, ɪt simd, wɑz ə kəmɑɾəti mɔɹ pɹɛʃəs ðən ɡoʊld.

Each of these experiences had moved her farther away from the Queen she had been. Now she didn't long for fine things or her throne. She just wanted some stability. That, it seemed, was a commodity more precious than gold.

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tæpɪŋ ðə mæp. "soʊ, wɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd? wi tʃeɪs æftɝ ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɑn fʊt fəɹ naʊ, sɛndɪŋ skaʊts baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ tə faɪn ðɛm, ɪf pɑsəbəl. hoʊpfəli, wɪl kætʃ əm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃ luɡɹd. haʊ lɔŋ tə ðə sɪɾi wəd jə seɪ, ɑɹɡændə?"

"It doesn't matter," Perrin said, tapping the map. "So, we're decided? We chase after Gill and the others on foot for now, sending scouts by gateway to find them, if possible. Hopefully, we'll catch them before they reach Lugard. How long to the city would you say, Arganda?"

"dɪpɛnz ɑn ðə mʌd," ðə wɪɹi soʊlʒɝ sɛd. "ðɛɹz ə ɹizən wi kɔl ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ ðə swɑmpɪŋ. waɪz mɛn doʊn tʃɹævəl dʊɹɪŋ ðə spɹɪŋ mɛlt."

"Depends on the mud," the wiry soldier said. "There's a reason we call this time of year the swamping. Wise men don't travel during the spring melt."

"wɪzdəm ɪz fəɹ ðoʊz u hæv taɪm fəɹ ɪt," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd, kaʊntɪŋ ɔf dɪstəns ɑn ðə mæp wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz.

"Wisdom is for those who have time for it," Perrin muttered, counting off distance on the map with his fingers.

mɔɹɡeɪs muv tə ɹifɪl ənʊɹəz kʌp. pɔɹɪŋ ti wɑz mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ðən ʃiɾ ɛvɝ əsumd. ʃi hæd tə noʊ huz kʌp tə teɪk əsaɪɾ ən fɪl, ən huz tə fɪl waɪl ðeɪ wɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɪt. ʃi hæd tə noʊ pɹɪsaɪsli haʊ haɪ tə fɪl ə kʌp soʊ ðəɾ ɪt wəd nɑt spɪl, ən haʊ tə pɔɹ ðə ti wɪθaʊt ɹætlɪŋ ðə pɔɹsələn əɹ splæʃɪŋ. ʃi nu wən tə nɑt bi sin ən wən tə meɪk ə slaɪt pɹədʌkʃən aʊɾ ə fɪlɪŋ kʌps ɪn keɪs ʃid mɪs pipəl, fɝɡɑɾən əm əɹ mɪsdʒʌdʒ ðɛɹ nidz.

Morgase moved to refill Annoura's cup. Pouring tea was more complicated than she'd ever assumed. She had to know whose cup to take aside and fill, and whose to fill while they were holding it. She had to know precisely how high to fill a cup so that it would not spill, and how to pour the tea without rattling the porcelain or splashing. She knew when to not be seen and when to make a slight production out of filling cups in case she'd missed people, forgotten them or misjudged their needs.

ʃi kɛɹfəli tʊk pɛɹɪnz kʌp fɹəm bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi laɪk tə dʒɛstʃɝ wən i spoʊk, ən kəd nɑk ðə kʌp fɹəm əɹ hæn ɪf ʃi wɑz ənwɛɹi. ɔl ɪn ɔl, ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ɑɹt tə sɝvɪŋ ti - ən ɪntaɪɝ wɝl ðət mɔɹɡeɪs ðə kwin hæd nɛvɝ bɑðɝd tə noʊɾəs. ʃi ɹifɪl pɛɹɪnz kʌp ən pleɪst ɪt bæk bɪsaɪd hɪm. pɛɹɪn æskt ʌðɝ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ðə mæp - nɪɹbaɪ taʊnz, pətɛnʃəl sɔɹsəz ə ɹisəp-plaɪ. hi hæɾ ə lɑɾ ə pɹɑməs əz ə liɾɝ, ivən ɪf i wɑz ɹæðɝ ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst. ə lɪɾəl ædvaɪs fɹəm mɔɹɡeɪs -  ʃi kʌt ðət θɔɾ ɔf. pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə wɑz ə ɹɛbəl. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ, ən hid neɪm hɪmsɛlf lɔɹɾ ʌv ɪt, flaɪɪŋ ðət wʊlfhɛd bænɝ. ət lis ðə flæɡ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən hæd bɪn teɪkən daʊn. flaɪɪŋ ðət hæd bɪn nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ən oʊpən dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ.

She carefully took Perrin's cup from beside him on the ground. He liked to gesture when he spoke, and could knock the cup from her hand if she was unwary. All in all, there was a remarkable art to serving tea - an entire world that Morgase the Queen had never bothered to notice. She refilled Perrin's cup and placed it back beside him. Perrin asked other questions about the map - nearby towns, potential sources of resup-ply. He had a lot of promise as a leader, even if he was rather inexperienced. A little advice from Morgase -  She cut that thought off. Perrin Aybara was a rebel. The Two Rivers was part of Andor, and he'd named himself lord of it, flying that wolfhead banner. At least the flag of Manetheren had been taken down. Flying that had been nothing short of an open declaration of war.

mɔɹɡeɪs noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɹɪsəld ɛvɹi taɪm sʌmwʌn neɪmd ɪm ə lɔɹd, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ dɪdn ɪntɛn tə ɔfɝ ɪm ɛni hɛlp. nɑɾ əntɪl ʃi dɪtɝmən haʊ tə muv ɪm bæk bɪniθ ðə kloʊk ə ði ændɔɝən mɑnɑɹki.

Morgase no longer bristled every time someone named him a lord, but she also didn't intend to offer him any help. Not until she determined how to move him back beneath the cloak of the Andoran monarchy.

bɪsaɪdz, mɔɹɡeɪs ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli ədmɪɾəd, feɪl ɪz ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɛni ædvaɪs aɪ wəd hæv.

Besides, Morgase grudgingly admitted, Faile is sharp enough to give any advice I would have.

feɪl wɑz æktʃəli  ə pɝfəkt kɑmpləmən tə pɛɹɪn. wɛɹ i wɑz ə blʌn ən lɛvəld læns ət tʃɑɹdʒ, ʃi wɑz ə sʌɾəl kævəlɹi baʊ. ðə kɑmbəneɪʃən ə ðə tu - wɪð feɪlz kənɛkʃənz tə ðə sɑldəiən θɹoʊn - wɑz wʌt ɹɪli wɝid mɔɹɡeɪs. jɛs, hid teɪkən daʊn ðə meɪnɛðɝən bænɝ, bʌt hiɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðət wʊlfhɛd bænɝ teɪkən daʊn bɪfɔɹ. ɔfən, fɝbɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ðə bɛst weɪ tə ɛnʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪt hæpənd.

Faile was actually a perfect complement to Perrin. Where he was a blunt and leveled lance at charge, she was a subtle cavalry bow. The combination of the two - with Faile's connections to the Saldaean throne - was what really worried Morgase. Yes, he'd taken down the Manetheren banner, but he'd ordered that wolfhead banner taken down before. Often, forbidding something was the best way to ensure that it happened.

æliændɝ ɛs kʌp wɑz hæf ɛmpti. mɔɹɡeɪs muvd oʊvɝ tə ɹifɪl ɪt; laɪk mɛni haɪbɹn leɪɾiz, æliændɝ ɔlweɪz ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ kʌp tə bi fʊl. æliændɝ ɡlænst ət mɔɹɡeɪs, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə feɪnt ɡlɪmɝ ə dɪskʌmfɝɾ ɪn ðoʊz aɪz. æliændɝ fɛlt ənsɝɾən wʌt ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp ʃəd bi. ðət wɑz kjʊɹiəs, əz æliændɝ hæd bɪn soʊ hɔɾi dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ kæptɪvəɾi. ðə pɝsən mɔɹɡeɪs hæd wʌns bɪn, ðə kwin, wɑntəd tə sɪɾ æliændɝ daʊn ən ɡɪv ə lɛŋθi ɛkspləneɪʃən ə haʊ tə bɛɾɝ meɪnteɪn əɹ ɡɹænduɹ.

Alliandre s cup was half empty. Morgase moved over to refill it; like many highborn ladies, Alliandre always expected her cup to be full. Alliandre glanced at Morgase, and there was a faint glimmer of discomfort in those eyes. Alliandre felt uncertain what their relationship should be. That was curious, as Alliandre had been so haughty during their captivity. The person Morgase had once been, the Queen, wanted to sit Alliandre down and give a lengthy explanation of how to better maintain her grandeur.

ʃiɾ əv tə lɝn ɑn əɹ oʊn. mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðə pɝsən ʃi hæd wʌns bɪn. ʃi wɑznt ʃʊɹ wʌt ʃi wɑz, bʌt ʃi wəd lɝn haʊ tə də hɝ duɾi əz ə leɪɾiz meɪd. ðɪs wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ ə pæʃən fəɹ hɝ. ə weɪ tə pɹuv tə hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wɑz stɪl stʃɹɔŋ, stɪl ə vælju.

She'd have to learn on her own. Morgase was no longer the person she had once been. She wasn't sure what she was, but she would learn how to do her duty as a lady's maid. This was becoming a passion for her. A way to prove to herself that she was still strong, still of value.

ɪn ə weɪ, ɪt wɑz tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ ðət ʃi wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðæt.

In a way, it was terrifying that she worried about that.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," æliændɝ sɛɾ əz mɔɹɡeɪs muvd əweɪ. "ɪz ɪt tʃɹu ðət jəɹ plænɪŋ ɑn sɛndɪŋ maɪ pipəl bæk tə dʒəhænə æftɝ jə faɪnd ɡɪl ən ɪz ɡɹup?"

"Lord Perrin," Alliandre said as Morgase moved away. "Is it true that you're planning on sending my people back to Jehannah after you find Gill and his group?"

mɔɹɡeɪs kəntɪnjud pæs mɑsʊɝi - ði ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪkt əɹ kʌp ɹifɪld oʊnli wən ʃi tæpt ɑn ɪt laɪtli wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪl.

Morgase continued past Masuri - the Aes Sedai liked her cup refilled only when she tapped on it lightly with her fingernail.

"aɪ du," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "wi ɔl noʊ ɪt wɑzn kəmplitli jəɹ wɪl tə dʒɔɪn əs ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ɪf wi hædn bɹɔt jə əlɔŋ, jud nɛvɝ əv bɪn kæptʃɝd baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. mæsimə ɪz dɛd. taɪm tə lɛt jə ɹɪtɝn tə ɡʌvɝnɪŋ jəɹ neɪʃən."

"I do," Perrin replied. "We all know it wasn't completely your will to join us in the first place. If we hadn't brought you along, you'd never have been captured by the Shaido. Masema is dead. Time to let you return to governing your nation."

"wɪð ɔl du ɹɪspɛkt, maɪ lɔɹd," æliændɝ sɛd. "waɪ ɑɹ jə ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ fɹəm əmʌŋ maɪ kʌntʃɹimɪn ɪf nɑt tə ɡæðɝ ən ɑɹmi fəɹ fjutʃɝ jus?"

"With all due respect, my Lord," Alliandre said. "Why are you recruiting from among my countrymen if not to gather an army for future use?"

"aɪm nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹəkɹut," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "dʒʌs kəz aɪ doʊn tɝn əm əweɪ dʌzn min aɪ ɪntɛn tə ɛnlɑɹdʒ ðɪs ɑɹmi ɛni fɝðɝ."

"I'm not trying to recruit," Perrin said. "Just because I don't turn them away doesn't mean I intend to enlarge this army any further."

"maɪ lɔɹd," æliændɝ sɛd. "bʌt ʃʊɹli ɪts waɪz tə kip wʌt jə hæv."

"My Lord," Alliandre said. "But surely it is wise to keep what you have."

"ʃi hæz ə pɔɪnt, pɛɹɪn," bɹəleɪn æɾəd sɔfli. "wʌn niɾ oʊnli lʊk ət ðə skaɪ tə noʊ ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz ɪmənənt. waɪ sɛn əɹ fɔɹs bæk? aɪm sɝɾən ðət ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɪl əv niɾ ʌv ɛvɹi soʊlʒɝ fɹəm ɛvɹi læn swɔɹn tə hɪm."

"She has a point, Perrin," Berelain added softly. "One need only look at the sky to know the Last Battle is imminent. Why send her force back? I'm certain that the Lord Dragon will have need of every soldier from every land sworn to him."

"hi kən sɛn fəɹ əm wən i dɪsaɪdz tə," pɛɹɪn sɛd stʌbɝnli.

"He can send for them when he decides to," Perrin said stubbornly.

"maɪ lɔɹd," æliændɝ sɛd. "aɪ dɪd nɑt swɛɹ tə hɪm. aɪ swɔɹ tə ju. ɪf ɡildən wɪl mɑɹtʃ fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən, ɪt ʃəd də soʊ bɪniθ jəɹ bænɝ."

"My Lord," Alliandre said. "I did not swear to him. I swore to you. If Ghealdan will march for Tarmon Gai'don, it should do so beneath your banner."

pɛɹɪn stʊɾ ʌp, stɑɹtlɪŋ sɛvɹəl pipəl ɪn ðə tɛnt. wɑz i livɪŋ? hi wɔk tə ði oʊpən saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd, poʊkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ aʊt. "wɪl, kʌm hɪɹ," hi kɔld.

Perrin stood up, startling several people in the tent. Was he leaving? He walked to the open side of the tent without a word, poking his head out. "Wil, come here," he called.

ə wiv ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ kɛpt pipəl aʊtsaɪd fɹəm lɪsnɪŋ ɪn. mɔɹɡeɪs kəd si mɑsʊɝiz wivz, taɪɾ ɔf ən wɔɹɾɪŋ ðə tɛnt. ðɛɹ ɪntʃɹəkəsi sim tə mɑk əɹ oʊn mɪnəskjul tælənt.

A weave of the One Power kept people outside from listening in. Morgase could see Masuri's weaves, tied off and warding the tent. Their intricacy seemed to mock her own minuscule talent.

mɑsʊɝi tæp ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ kʌp, ən mɔɹɡeɪs heɪsən tə ɹifɪl ɪt. ðə wʊmən laɪk tə sɪp ti wən nɝvəs.

Masuri tapped the side of her cup, and Morgase hastened to refill it. The woman liked to sip tea when nervous.

pɛɹɪn tɝn bæk ɪndə ðə tɛnt, fɑloʊd baɪ ə hænsəm juθ kæɹiɪŋ ə klɔθ-ɹæp bʌndəl.

Perrin turned back into the tent, followed by a handsome youth carrying a cloth-wrapped bundle.

"ənfɝl ɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. ðə jʌŋ mæn dɪd soʊ, lʊkɪŋ æpɹɪhɛnsɪv. ɪt bɔɹ ðə wʊlfhɛɾ ɛmbləm ðət wɑz pɛɹɪnz sɪdʒəl.

"Unfurl it," Perrin said. The young man did so, looking apprehensive. It bore the wolfhead emblem that was Perrin's sigil.

"aɪ dɪdn meɪk ðɪs bænɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ nɛvɝ wɑntəɾ ɪt, bʌt -  əpɑn ædvaɪs - aɪ lɛɾ ɪt flaɪ. wɛl, ðə ɹizənz fəɹ duɪŋ ðəɾ ɑɹ pæst. aɪɾ ɔɹɾɝ ðə θɪŋ teɪkən daʊn, bʌt ðət nɛvɝ simz tə wɝk fəɹ lɔŋ." hi lʊk tə wɪl. "wɪl, aɪ wɑn ɪt pæs θɹu kæmp. aɪm ɡɪvɪŋ ə dɝɛkt ɔɹɾɝ. aɪ wɑn itʃ ən ɛvɹi kɑpi ʌv ðɪs blæstəd bænɝ bɝnd. jə ʌndɝstænd?"

"I didn't make this banner," Perrin said. "I never wanted it, but -  upon advice - I let it fly. Well, the reasons for doing that are past. I'd order the thing taken down, but that never seems to work for long." He looked to Wil. "Wil, I want it passed through camp. I'm giving a direct order. I want each and every copy of this blasted banner burned. You understand?"

wɪl peɪld. "bʌt - "

Wil paled. "But - "

"du ɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æliændɝ, jəl swɛɹ tə ɹænd əz sun əz wi faɪn hɪm. jə woʊn ɹaɪd bɪniθ maɪ bænɝ, kəz aɪ woʊn əv ə bænɝ. ɪm ə blæksmɪθ, ən ðæts ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. aɪv stʌmɑtʃt ðɪs fulɪʃnəs fəɹ tu lɔŋ."

"Do it," Perrin said. "Alliandre, you'll swear to Rand as soon as we find him. You won't ride beneath my banner, because I won't have a banner. I'm a blacksmith, and that's the end of it. I've stomached this foolishness for too long."

"pɛɹɪn?" feɪl æskt. ʃi lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd. "ɪz ðɪs waɪz?"

"Perrin?" Faile asked. She looked surprised. "Is this wise?"

ful mæn. hi ʃəɾ əv ət lis tɔk tə hɪz waɪf əbaʊt ðɪs. bʌt mɛn wəd bi mɛn. ðeɪ laɪk ðɛɹ sikɹəts ən ðɛɹ plænz.

Fool man. He should have at least talked to his wife about this. But men would be men. They liked their secrets and their plans.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ɪts waɪz. bʌɾ ɪt wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ," hi sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn. bi ɔf, wɪl. aɪ wɑn ðoʊz bænɝz bɝn baɪ tənaɪt. noʊ hoʊldaʊts, jə ʌndɝstænd?"

"I don't know if it's wise. But it what I'm doing," he said, sitting down. Be off, Wil. I want those banners burned by tonight. No holdouts, you understand?"

wɪl stɪfənd, ðən spʌn ən stʃɹoʊd fɹəm ðə tɛnt wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ə ɹɪplaɪ. ðə læd lʊkt əz ɪf i fɛl bɪtʃɹeɪd. ɑdli, mɔɹɡeɪs faʊn hɝsɛlf filɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ə ðə seɪm. ɪt wɑz fulɪʃ. ðɪs wɑz wʌt ʃi wɑntəd - ɪt wɑz wʌt pɛɹɪn ʃəd du. ən jɛt, ðə pipəl wɝ fɹaɪɾənd, wɪð ɡʊd ɹizən.

Wil stiffened, then spun and strode from the tent without giving a reply. The lad looked as if he felt betrayed. Oddly, Morgase found herself feeling a little of the same. It was foolish. This was what she wanted - it was what Perrin should do. And yet, the people were frightened, with good reason.

ðət skaɪ, ðə θɪŋz ðət wɝ hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld . . . wɛl, ɪn ə taɪm laɪk ðɪs, pɝhæps ə mæn kəd bi ɪkskjuz fəɹ teɪkɪŋ kəmænd.

That sky, the things that were happening in the world . . . Well, in a time like this, perhaps a man could be excused for taking command.

"ju ɑɹ ə ful, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," mɑsʊɝi sɛd. ʃi hæɾ ə blʌnt weɪ əbaʊt hɝ.

"You are a fool, Perrin Aybara," Masuri said. She had a blunt way about her.

"sʌn," tɑɹn ədʒɹɛs pɛɹɪn, "ðə lædz pʊɾ ə lɑɾ ə stɑk ɪn ðət bænɝ."

"Son," Tarn addressed Perrin, "the lads put a lot of stock in that banner."

"tu mʌtʃ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Too much," Perrin said.

"pɝhæps. bʌɾ ɪts ɡʊd tə hæv sʌmθɪŋ tə lʊk tə. wən jə tʊk daʊn ði ʌðɝ bænɝ, ɪt wɑz hɑɹɾ ɑn ðɛm. ðɪs wɪl bi wɝs."

"Perhaps. But it's good to have something to look to. When you took down the other banner, it was hard on them. This will be worse."

"ɪt nidz tə bi dʌn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn əv ɡɑɾən tu ətætʃt tə ɪt, stɑɹɾəd tɔkɪŋ laɪk ðəɹ gɑnə steɪ wɪð mi ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə ðɛɹ fæmliz wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ.

"It needs to be done," Perrin said. "The Two Rivers men have gotten too attached to it, started talking like they're going to stay with me instead of going back to their families where they belong.

wən wi ɡɛt ɡeɪtweɪz wɝkɪŋ əɡɛn, tɑɹn, jəl bi teɪkɪŋ əm ən ɡoʊɪŋ." hi lʊkt ət bɹəleɪn.

When we get gateways working again, Tarn, you'll be taking them and going." He looked at Berelain.

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kæn bi ɹɪɾ ə jə ən jəɹ mɛn. jəl ɡoʊ bæk wɪð mi tə ɹænd."

"I suppose I can't be rid of you and your men. You'll go back with me to Rand."

"aɪ wɑzn əwɛɹ," bɹəleɪn sɛd stɪfli, "ðæt jə niɾəd tə 'bi ɹɪd' ʌv ʌs. jə sim fɑɹ lɛs ɹɪlʌktən tə æksɛp maɪ səpɔɹt wən dɪmændɪŋ ðə sɝvəsəz ə maɪ wɪŋd ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɪn ɹɛskjuɪŋ jəɹ waɪf."

"I wasn't aware," Berelain said stiffly, "that you needed to 'be rid' of us. You seemed far less reluctant to accept my support when demanding the services of my Winged Guardsmen in rescuing your wife."

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ əpɹiʃieɪt jəɹ hɛlp, ɔl ə ju. wi dɪɾ ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ɪn meɪɾən, ən nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ feɪl ən æliændɝ. ɪt wɑz ə θɪŋ ðət niɾəd duɪŋ. bʌt bɝn mi, ðæts oʊvɝ naʊ. ɪf jə wɑnə ɡoʊ ɑn tə fɑloʊ ɹænd, aɪm ʃʊɹ hɪl əv ju. bʌt maɪ æʃəmən ɑɹ ɪɡzɔstəd, ən ðə tæsks aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən ɑɹ kəmplit. aɪv ɡɑt ðiz hʊks ɪnsaɪɾ ə mi, pʊlɪŋ mi bæk tə ɹænd. bɪfɔɹ aɪ kən də ðæt, aɪ nid tə bi dʌn wɪð ɔl ə ju."

Perrin took a deep breath. "I appreciate your help, all of you. We did a good thing in Maiden, and not just for Faile and Alliandre. It was a thing that needed doing. But burn me, that's over now. If you want to go on to follow Rand, I'm sure he'll have you. But my Asha'man are exhausted, and the tasks I was given are complete. I've got these hooks inside of me, pulling me back to Rand. Before I can do that, I need to be done with all of you."

"hʌzbənd," feɪl sɛd, hɝ wɝdz klɪpt. "maɪɾ aɪ sədʒɛs ðət wi bɪɡɪn wɪð ðə wʌnz u wɑnə bi sɛn əweɪ?"

"Husband," Faile said, her words clipped. "Might I suggest that we begin with the ones who want to be sent away?"

"jɛs," ɝɑvin sɛd. ðə fɔɹmɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn sæt nɪɹ ðə bæk ə ðə tɛnt, izi tə oʊvɝlʊk, ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪkʌm ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt fɔɹs ɪn pɛɹɪnz kæmp ædmɪnɪstʃɹeɪʃən. ʃi æktəɾ əz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ən ʌnəfɪʃəl stuɝd fəɹ hɪm. "sʌm ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz wəd bi hæpi tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ hoʊmz."

"Yes," Aravine said. The former gai'shain sat near the back of the tent, easy to overlook, though she had become an important force in Perrin's camp administration. She acted as something of an unofficial steward for him. "Some of the refugees would be happy to return to their homes."

"aɪd ɹæðɝ muv ɛvɹiwʌn, ɪf aɪ kæn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɡɹeɪɾi?"

"I'd rather move everyone, if I can," Perrin said. "Grady?"

ði æʃəmən ʃɹʌɡd ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. "ðə ɡeɪtweɪz aɪv meɪd fəɹ skaʊts hævən tæks mi tu mʌtʃ, ən aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kəd meɪk səm lɑɹdʒɝ wʌnz. aɪm stɪl ə lɪɾəl wik, bʌɾ aɪm moʊsli oʊvɝ ðə sɪknəs. nild wɪl nid mɔɹ taɪm, ðoʊ."

The Asha'man shrugged his shoulders. "The gateways I've made for scouts haven't taxed me too much, and I think I could make some larger ones. I'm still a little weak, but I am mostly over the sickness. Neald will need more time, though."

"maɪ lɔɹd." beɪlwɝ kɔf sɔfli. "aɪ hæv səm fɪɡjɝz ə kjʊɹiəs noʊt. muvɪŋ əz mɛni pipəl əz jə naʊ hæv θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz wɪl teɪk aʊɝz, meɪbi deɪz. ɪt woʊn bi ə kwɪk ɪndɛvɝ, əz wən wi əpɹoʊtʃt meɪɾən."

"My Lord." Balwer coughed softly. "I have some figures of curious note. Moving as many people as you now have through gateways will take hours, maybe days. It won't be a quick endeavor, as when we approached Maiden."

"ðæts gɑnə bi ɹʌf, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ kəd hoʊld wʌn oʊpən sətʃ ə lɔŋ taɪm. nɑɾ ɪf jə wɑn mi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi ɪn faɪɾɪŋ ʃeɪp, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs."

"That's going to be rough, my Lord," Grady said. "I don't think I could hold one open such a long time. Not if you want me strong enough to be in fighting shape, just in case."

pɛɹɪn sɛɾəld bæk daʊn, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə mæp əɡɛn. bɹəleɪnz kʌp wɑz ɛmpti; mɔɹɡeɪs hɝiɾ oʊvɝ tə fɪl ɪt. "ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wil stɑɹt sɛndɪŋ səm smɔlɝ ɡɹups ə ɹɛfjudʒiz əweɪ, bʌt ðoʊz u wɑnə liv fɝst."

Perrin settled back down, inspecting the map again. Berelain's cup was empty; Morgase hurried over to fill it. "All right, then," Perrin said. "We'll start sending some smaller groups of refugees away, but those who want to leave first."

"ɔlsoʊ," feɪl sɛd. "pɝhæps ɪts taɪm tə sɛn mɛsənʒɝz tə kɑntæk ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən; hi maɪt bi wɪlɪŋ tə sɛn mɔɹ æʃəmən."

"Also," Faile said. "Perhaps it is time to send messengers to contact the Lord Dragon; he might be willing to send more Asha'man."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "jɛs."

Perrin nodded. "Yes."

"læst wi nu," siɑnɪd sɛd, "hi wɑz ɪn kɛɹhin. ðə lɑɹdʒəs nʌmbɝ ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz ɑɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ, soʊ wi kəd bɪɡɪn baɪ sɛndɪŋ səm ə ðɛm hoʊm, əlɔŋ wɪð skaʊts tə mit wɪð ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən."
