"Last we knew," Seonid said, "he was in Cairhien. The largest number of the refugees are from there, so we could begin by sending some of them home, along with scouts to meet with the Lord Dragon."

"hiz nɑt ðɛɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"He's not there," Perrin said.

"haʊ dʒju noʊ?" ɛdʒɹə sɛt daʊn əɹ kʌp. mɔɹɡeɪs kɹɛpt ɝaʊn ðə pɝɪməɾɝ ə ðə tɛn ən snætʃt ɪt fəɹ ɹifɪlɪŋ. ɛldəst ə ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən pɝhæps fɔɹmoʊst əmʌŋ əm - ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl wɪð waɪz wʌnz - ɛdʒɹə lʊk stʃɹaɪkɪŋli jʌŋ fəɹ əɹ ɹipɔɹɾəd eɪdʒ. mɔɹɡeɪsəz oʊn taɪni əbɪləɾi ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz ɪnʌf tə tɛl əɹ ðət ðɪs wʊmən wɑz stʃɹɔŋ. pɹɑbli ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɪn ðə ɹum.

"How do you know?" Edarra set down her cup. Morgase crept around the perimeter of the tent and snatched it for refilling. Eldest of the Wise Ones, and perhaps foremost among them - it was hard to tell with Wise Ones - Edarra looked strikingly young for her reported age. Morgase's own tiny ability in the One Power was enough to tell her that this woman was strong. Probably the strongest in the room.

"aɪ . . ." pɛɹɪn sim tə flaʊndɝ. hæɾ i ə sɔɹs ʌv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən i wɑznt ʃɛɹɪŋ? "ɹæn əz ə hæbəɾ ə biɪŋ wɛɹ jə doʊn ɪkspɛk hɪm. aɪ daʊt hiz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kɛɹhin. bʌt siɑnɪɾ ɪz ɹaɪt - ɪts ðə bɛs pleɪs tə stɑɹt lʊkɪŋ."

"I . . ." Perrin seemed to flounder. Had he a source of information he wasn't sharing? "Rand has a habit of being where you don't expect him. I doubt he's remained in Cairhien. But Seonid is right - it's the best place to start looking."

"maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛd. "aɪ wɝi əbaʊt wʌt wi maɪt, əhɛm, blʌndɝ ɪndə ɪf wəɹ nɑt kɛɹfəl.

"My Lord," Balwer said. "I worry about what we might, ahem, blunder into if we are not careful.

flits ə ɹɛfjudʒiz, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli? wɪv bɪn aʊɾ ə tʌtʃ fəɹ səm taɪm. pɝhæps, ɪn ədɪʃən tə kɑntæktɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən, wi kəd sɛn skaʊts tə ɡæðɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən?"

Fleets of refugees, returning through gateways unexpectedly? We have been out of touch for some time. Perhaps, in addition to contacting the Dragon, we could send scouts to gather information?"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪ kəɾ əpɹuv ðæt."

Perrin nodded. "I could approve that."

beɪlwɝ sɛɾəld bæk, lʊkɪŋ plizd, ðoʊ ðət mæn wɑz stʃɹaɪkɪŋli ɡʊɾ ət haɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz.

Balwer settled back, looking pleased, though that man was strikingly good at hiding his emotions.

waɪ dɪɾ i wɑn soʊ bædli tə sɛn sʌmwʌn tə kɛɹhin?

Why did he want so badly to send someone to Cairhien?

"aɪl ədmɪt," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, "aɪm wɝiɾ əbaʊt muvɪŋ ɔl ə ðiz pipəl. ivən wʌns nild ɪz wɛl, ɪts gɑnə bi ɪɡzɔstɪŋ tə hoʊld ɡeɪtweɪz oʊpən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡɛɾ əm ɔl θɹu."

"I'll admit," Grady said, "I'm worried about moving all of these people. Even once Neald is well, it's going to be exhausting to hold gateways open long enough to get them all through."

"pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɛdʒɹə sɛd. "ðɛɹ meɪ bi ə weɪ tə fɪks ðɪs pɹɑbləm."

"Perrin Aybara," Edarra said. "There may be a way to fix this problem."

"haʊ?"

"How?"

"ðiz əpɹɛntəsɪz əv bɪn spikɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ. ə sɝkəl, ɪts kɔld? ɪf wi lɪŋk təɡɛðɝ, ði æʃəmən ən səm ʌv ʌs, ðən pɝhæps wi kəd ɡɪv əm ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə kɹieɪt lɑɹdʒɝ ɡeɪtweɪz."

"These apprentices have been speaking of something. A circle, it is called? If we linked together, the Ashaman and some of us, then perhaps we could give them the strength to create larger gateways."

pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt əɾ ɪz bɪɹd. "ɡɹeɪɾi?"

Perrin scratched at his beard. "Grady?"

"aɪv nɛvɝ lɪŋkt ɪn ə sɝkəl bɪfɔɹ, maɪ lɔɹd. bʌɾ ɪf wi kəd fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊtwɛl, bɪɡɝ ɡeɪtweɪz wəd muv mɔɹ pipəl θɹu fæstɝ. ðət kəd hɛlp ə lɑt."

"I've never linked in a circle before, my Lord. But if we could figure it out...well, bigger gateways would move more people through faster. That could help a lot."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðə waɪz wʌn. "wʌt wəɾ ɪt kɑs mi fəɹ jə tə tʃɹaɪ ðɪs?"

"All right," Perrin said, turning back to the Wise One. "What would it cost me for you to try this?"

"ju hæv wɝk tu lɔŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɛdʒɹə sɛd wɪð ə snɪf. "nɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ mʌs bi dʌn əɾ ə kɑst. ðɪs wɪl bɛnəfɪɾ əs ɔl. aɪ hæv bɪn kɑntəmpleɪɾɪŋ sədʒɛstɪŋ ɪt fəɹ səm taɪm."

"You have worked too long with Aes Sedai, Perrin Aybara," Edarra said with a sniff. "Not everything must be done at a cost. This will benefit us all. I have been contemplating suggesting it for some time."

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. "haʊ lɔŋ əv jə noʊn ðət ðɪs maɪt wɝk?"

Perrin frowned. "How long have you known that this might work?"

"lɔŋ ɪnʌf."

"Long enough."

"bɝn ju, wʊmən, waɪ dɪdn jə bɹɪŋ ɪt tə mi ɝliɝ, ðɛn?"

"Burn you, woman, why didn't you bring it to me earlier, then?"

"ju sim hɑɹdli ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn jəɹ pəzɪʃən əz tʃif, moʊst ə ðə taɪm," ɛdʒɹə sɛd koʊldli.

"You seem hardly interested in your position as chief, most of the time," Edarra said coldly.

"ɹɪspɛkt ɪz ə θɪŋ ɝn ən nɑt dɪmændəd, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

"Respect is a thing earned and not demanded, Perrin Aybara."

mɔɹɡeɪs hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ ət ðəɾ ɪnsələn kɑmɛnt. mɛni ə lɔɹd wəd snæp ət sʌmwʌn fəɹ ðət toʊn. pɛɹɪn fɹoʊz, bʌt ðən nɑɾəd, əz ɪf ðət wɝ ði ɪkspɛktəɾ ænsɝ.

Morgase held her breath at that insolent comment. Many a lord would snap at someone for that tone. Perrin froze, but then nodded, as if that were the expected answer.

"jɔɹ æʃəmən wɝ sɪk wən aɪ fɝs θɔɾ ə ðɪs," ɛdʒɹə kəntɪnjud. "ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv wɝk bɪfɔɹ. ðɪs ɪz ði əpɹoʊpɹiət taɪm tə ɹeɪz ðə kwɛstʃən. ðɛɹfɔɹ, aɪ hæv dʌn soʊ."

"Your Asha'man were sick when I first thought of this," Edarra continued. "It would not have worked before. This is the appropriate time to raise the question. Therefore, I have done so."

ʃi ɪnsəls ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð wʌn bɹɛθ, mɔɹɡeɪs θɔt, ðən æks dʒʌs laɪk wʌn wɪð ðə nɛkst. stɪl, biɪŋ ə kæptɪv ɪn meɪɾən hæd hɛlp mɔɹɡeɪs bɪɡɪn tə ʌndɝstæn il weɪz. ɛvɹiwʌn kleɪm ði il wɝ ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv tɔk laɪk ðət lɪɾəl kɹiɾəns. il wɝ pipəl, laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ. ðeɪ hæɾ ɑd tʃɹədɪʃənz ən kʌltʃɝəl kwɝks, bʌt soʊ dɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. ə kwin hæd tə bi eɪbəl tə ʌndɝstæn ɔl ə ðə pipəl wɪðɪn əɹ ɹɛlm -  ən ɔl ə hɝ ɹɛlmz pətɛnʃəl ɛnəmiz.

She insults Aes Sedai with one breath, Morgase thought, then acts just like one with the next. Still, being a captive in Maiden had helped Morgase begin to understand Aiel ways. Everyone claimed the Aiel were incomprehensible, but she gave talk like that little credence. Aiel were people, like any other. They had odd traditions and cultural quirks, but so did everyone else. A queen had to be able to understand all of the people within her realm -  and all of her realm's potential enemies.

"vɛɹi wɛl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɡɹeɪɾi, doʊn fətiɡ jɝsɛlf tu mʌtʃ, bʌt stɑɹt wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðɛm.

"Very well," Perrin said. "Grady, don't fatigue yourself too much, but start working with them.

si ɪf jə kən mænədʒ fɔɹmɪŋ ə sɝkəl."

See if you can manage forming a circle."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. ði æʃəmən ɔlweɪz sim sʌmwʌt dɪstənt. "maɪt bi ɡʊd tə ɪnvɑlv nild ɪn ðɪs. hi ɡɛts dɪzi wən i stænz, bʌt hiz bɪn ɪtʃɪŋ tə də sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ðɪs maɪt bi ə weɪ fəɹ ɪm tə ɡɛt bæk ɪndə pɹæktəs."

"Yes, my Lord," Grady said. The Asha'man always seemed somewhat distant. "Might be good to involve Neald in this. He gets dizzy when he stands, but he's been itching to do something with the Power. This might be a way for him to get back into practice."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"All right," Perrin said.

"wi hæv nɑt fɪnɪʃt tɔkɪŋ ə ðə skaʊts wəɹ sɛndɪŋ tə kɛɹhin," siɑnɪd sɛd. "aɪ wəd laɪk tə bi wɪð ðə ɡɹup."

"We have not finished talking of the scouts we are sending to Cairhien," Seonid said. "I would like to be with the group."

pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ɪz bɪɹɾəd tʃɪn. "aɪ səpoʊz. teɪk jəɹ wɔɹɾɝz, tu meɪɾənz ən pɛl eɪdɑɹ.

Perrin scratched his bearded chin. "I suppose. Take your Warders, two Maidens and Pel Aydaer.

bi ʌnəbtʃɹusɪv, ɪf jə kæn."

Be unobtrusive, if you can."

"ɔlsoʊ kɑmɛl noʊlsən wɪl ɡoʊ," feɪl sɛd. ʌv kɔɹs ʃi wəɾ æd wʌn tʃɑ feɪl tə ðə ɡɹup.

"Also Camaille Nolaisen will go," Faile said. Of course she would add one Cha Faile to the group.

beɪlwɝ klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "maɪ lɔɹd. wəɹ ɪn daɪɹ niɾ ə peɪpɝ ən nu pɛn nɪbz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən səm ʌðɝ dɛləkət mətɪɹiəlz."

Balwer cleared his throat. "My Lord. We are in dire need of paper and new pen nibs, not to mention some other delicate materials."

"ʃʊɹli ðət kən weɪt." pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd.

"Surely that can wait." Perrin frowned.

"noʊ," feɪl sɛd sloʊli. '"noʊ, hʌzbənd, aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz ə ɡʊd sədʒɛstʃən. wi ʃəd sɛnd wʌn pɝsən tə kəlɛk səplaɪz. beɪlwɝ, wəd jə ɡoʊ ən fɛtʃ ðə θɪŋz jɝsɛlf?"

"No," Faile said slowly. '"No, husband, I think this is a good suggestion. We should send one person to collect supplies. Balwer, would you go and fetch the things yourself?"

"ɪf maɪ leɪɾi wɪʃɪz ɪt," ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi sɛd. "aɪ hæv ætʃt tə vɪzət ðɪs skul ðə dʒɹæɡən əz oʊpən ɪn kɛɹhin. ðeɪ wəɾ əv ðə səplaɪz wi nid."

"If my Lady wishes it," the secretary said. "I have ached to visit this school the Dragon has opened in Cairhien. They would have the supplies we need."

"aɪ səpoʊz jə kən ɡoʊ, ðɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌt noʊbɑdi ɛls. laɪt! ɛni mɔɹ, ən wi maɪɾ əz wɛl sɛn ðə hoʊl bɝnɪŋ ɑɹmi θɹu."

"I suppose you can go, then," Perrin said. "But nobody else. Light! Any more, and we might as well send the whole burning army through."

beɪlwɝ nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ sæɾəsfaɪd. ðət wʌn wɑz ɑbviəsli spaɪɪŋ fəɹ pɛɹɪn naʊ. wəɾ i tɛl eɪbɑɹə hu ʃi ɹɪli wɑz? hæɾ i dʌn soʊ ɔlɹɛɾi? pɛɹɪn dɪdn ækt əz ɪf i nu.

Balwer nodded, looking satisfied. That one was obviously spying for Perrin now. Would he tell Aybara who she really was? Had he done so already? Perrin didn't act as if he knew.

ʃi ɡæðɝɾ ʌp mɔɹ kʌps; ðə miɾɪŋ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ʌp. ʌv kɔɹs beɪlwɝ wəɾ ɔfɝ tə spaɪ fəɹ eɪbɑɹə; ʃi ʃʊɾə əpɹoʊtʃt ðə dʌsti mæn ɝliɝ, tə si wʌt ðə pɹaɪs wəd bi tə kip ɪz saɪləns. mɪsteɪks laɪk ðət kəd kɑst ə kwin əɹ θɹoʊn.

She gathered up more cups; the meeting was beginning to break up. Of course Balwer would offer to spy for Aybara; she should have approached the dusty man earlier, to see what the price would be to keep his silence. Mistakes like that could cost a queen her throne.

ʃi fɹoʊz, hæn hæfweɪ tə ə kʌp. jəɹ nɑɾ ə kwin ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. juv tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk wʌn!

She froze, hand halfway to a cup. You're not a queen any longer. You have to stop thinking like one!

dʊɹɪŋ ðə fɝst wiks fɑloʊɪŋ əɹ saɪlən æbdɪkeɪʃən, ʃid hoʊp tə faɪn ə weɪ tə ɹɪtɝn tə ændɝ, soʊ ʃi kəd bi ə ɹisɔɹs fəɹ ɪleɪn. haʊɛvɝ, ðə mɔɹ ʃid kənsɪɾɝd ɪt, ðə mɔɹ ʃid ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd tə steɪ əweɪ. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ændɝ hæd tə əsum ðət mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz dɛd. itʃ kwin hæd tə meɪk əɹ oʊn weɪ, ən ɪleɪn maɪt sim ə pʌpət tə hɝ oʊn mʌðɝ ɪf mɔɹɡeɪs ɹɪtɝnd. bɪɑn ðæt, mɔɹɡeɪs hæd meɪd mɛni ɛnəmiz bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ. waɪ hæd ʃi dʌn sətʃ θɪŋz? hɝ mɛmɹi ʌv ðoʊz taɪmz wɑz klaʊɾi, bʌɾ əɹ ɹɪtɝn wəɾ oʊnli ɹɪp oʊpən oʊld wunz.

During the first weeks following her silent abdication, she'd hoped to find a way to return to Andor, so she could be a resource for Elayne. However, the more she'd considered it, the more she'd realized that she had to stay away. Everyone in Andor had to assume that Morgase was dead. Each queen had to make her own way, and Elayne might seem a puppet to her own mother if Morgase returned. Beyond that, Morgase had made many enemies before leaving. Why had she done such things? Her memory of those times was cloudy, but her return would only rip open old wounds.

ʃi kəntɪnjud ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp kʌps. pɝhæps ʃi ʃʊɾə dʌn ðə noʊbəl θɪŋ ən kɪl hɝsɛlf.

She continued gathering up cups. Perhaps she should have done the noble thing and killed herself.

ɪf ɛnəmiz ə ðə θɹoʊn dɪskʌvɝɾ u ʃi wɑz, ðeɪ kəd juz əɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪn, ðə seɪm weɪ ðət ðə waɪtkloʊks wəd hæv. bʌt fəɹ naʊ, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə θɹɛt. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wɑz kɑnfəɾənt ðəɾ ɪleɪn wəd nɑt ɹɪsk ændɝz seɪfti, ivən tə seɪv əɹ mʌðɝ.

If enemies of the throne discovered who she was, they could use her against Elayne, the same way that the Whitecloaks would have. But for now, she was not a threat. Besides, she was confident that Elayne would not risk Andor's safety, even to save her mother.

pɛɹɪn beɪd fɛɹwɛl tə ði ətɛndiz ən ɡeɪv səm beɪsɪk ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fəɹ ði ivnɪŋ kæmp.

Perrin bade farewell to the attendees and gave some basic instructions for the evening camp.

mɔɹɡeɪs nɛl daʊn, juzɪŋ ə ɹæɡ tə waɪp dɝt fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə tikʌp ðət hæd ɹoʊld oʊvɝ. naɪl hæd toʊld əɹ ðət ɡeɪbɹəl wɑz dɛd, ən ælθɹ hɛl keɪɛmlɪn. ðət wʊɾə pɹɑmptəɾ ɪleɪn tə ɹɪtɝn, wʊdn ɪt? wɑz ʃi kwin? hæd ðə haʊsəz səpɔɹɾəd hɝ, əɹ hæd ðeɪ æktəɾ əɡɛnst əɹ kəz ʌv wʌt mɔɹɡeɪs hæd dʌn?

Morgase knelt down, using a rag to wipe dirt from the side of a teacup that had rolled over. Niall had told her that Gaebril was dead, and al'Thor held Caemlyn. That would have prompted Elayne to return, wouldn't it? Was she queen? Had the Houses supported her, or had they acted against her because of what Morgase had done?

ðə skaʊɾɪŋ pɑɹɾi maɪt bɹɪŋ nuz ðət mɔɹɡeɪs hʌŋɡɝd fɔɹ. ʃi wəɾ əv tə faɪn ə weɪ ɪndə ɛni miɾɪŋ dɪskʌsɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts, pɝ-hæps baɪ ɔfɝɪŋ tə sɝv ðə ti. ðə bɛɾɝ ʃi ɡɹu əɾ əɹ dʒɑb əz feɪlz meɪd, ðə kloʊsɝ ʃid bi eɪbəl tə ɡɛt tə ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪvɛns.

The scouting party might bring news that Morgase hungered for. She would have to find a way into any meeting discussing their reports, per-haps by offering to serve the tea. The better she grew at her job as Faile's maid, the closer she'd be able to get to important events.

əz ðə waɪz wʌnz meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ fɹəm ðə tɛnt, mɔɹɡeɪs kɑt saɪɾ ə sʌmwʌn aʊtsaɪd.

As the Wise Ones made their way from the tent, Morgase caught sight of someone outside.

tɑlænvɝ, duɾifəl əz ɔlweɪz. tɔl, bɹɔɾ ə ʃoʊldɝ, hi wɔɹ ɪz sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst ən ə lʊk ə pɔɪntəd kənsɝn ɪn ɪz aɪz.

Tallanvor, dutiful as always. Tall, broad of shoulder, he wore his sword at his waist and a look of pointed concern in his eyes.

hid fɑloʊɾ əɹ pɹæktəkli nɑnstɑp sɪns meɪɾən, ən waɪl ʃid kəmpleɪn ʌv ɪɾ aʊɾ ə pɹɪnsəpəl, ʃi dɪdn maɪnd. æftɝ tu mʌnθs əpɑɹɾ i wɑntəd tə teɪk ɛvɹi ɑpɝtunəɾi tə bi təɡɛðɝ.

He'd followed her practically nonstop since Maiden, and while she'd complained of it out of principle, she didn't mind. After two months apart he wanted to take every opportunity to be together.

lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðoʊz bjuɾəfəl jʌŋ aɪz ə hɪz, ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɛntɝteɪn ðə noʊʃən ə suəsaɪɾ ivən fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ændɝ. ʃi fɛlt ə ful fəɹ ðæt. hædnt ʃi lɛɾ əɹ hɑɹt lɛɾ əɹ ɪndə ɪnʌf tʃɹʌbəl ɔlɹɛɾi?

Looking into those beautiful young eyes of his, she could not entertain the notion of suicide even for the good of Andor. She felt a fool for that. Hadn't she let her heart lead her into enough trouble already?

meɪɾən hæd tʃeɪnʒd hɝ, ðoʊ. ʃid mɪs tɑlænvɝ dɪɹli. ən ðən hid kʌm fəɹ hɝ, wən i ʃʊdn əv ɹɪsk hɪmsɛlf soʊ. hi wɑz mɔɹ dɪvoʊɾəd tə hɝ ðən tə ændɝ ɪtsɛlf. ən fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðət wɑz ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃi niɾəd. ʃi bɪɡæn tə meɪk əɹ weɪ təwɔɹd hɪm, bælənsɪŋ eɪt kʌps ɪn ðə kɹʊk ə hɝ ɑɹm waɪl kæɹiɪŋ ðə sɔsɝz ɪn əɹ hænd.

Maiden had changed her, though. She'd missed Tallanvor dearly. And then he'd come for her, when he shouldn't have risked himself so. He was more devoted to her than to Andor itself. And for some reason, that was exactly what she needed. She began to make her way toward him, balancing eight cups in the crook of her arm while carrying the saucers in her hand.

"meɪaɪɡdɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ əz ʃi pæst aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, tɝnɪŋ bæk. ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt pɛɹɪn ən ɪz waɪf hæd wɪθdʒɹɔn.

"Maighdin," Perrin said as she passed out of the tent. She hesitated, turning back. Everyone but Perrin and his wife had withdrawn.

"kʌm bæk hɪɹ, pliz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn tɑlænvɝ, jə maɪɾ əz wɛl kʌm ɪn. aɪ kən si jə lɝkɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ. ɑnəsli. ɪts nɑɾ əz ɪf ɛniwʌn wɑz gɑnə swup daʊn ən stil əɹ əweɪ waɪl ʃi wɑz ɪnsaɪɾ ə tɛn fʊl ʌv waɪz wʌnz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ!"

"Come back here, please," Perrin said. "And Tallanvor, you might as well come in. I can see you lurking out there. Honestly. It's not as if anyone was going to swoop down and steal her away while she was inside a tent full of Wise Ones and Aes Sedai!"

mɔɹɡeɪs ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. fɹəm wʌt ʃid sin, pɛɹɪn hɪmsɛlf hæd fɑloʊd feɪl ɝaʊn leɪtli nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ.

Morgase raised an eyebrow. From what she'd seen, Perrin himself had followed Faile around lately nearly as much.

tɑlænvɝ ʃɑɾ əɹ ə smaɪl əz i ɛntɝd. hi tʊk səm ə ðə kʌps fɹəm əɹ ɑɹm, ðən boʊθ ə ðɛm pɹizɛntəd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn. tɑlænvɝ baʊd fɔɹməli, wɪtʃ ɡeɪv mɔɹɡeɪs ə stæb ʌv ənɔɪəns. hi wɑz stɪl ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd - ði oʊnli lɔɪəl mɛmbɝ, əz fɑɹ əz ʃi nu.

Tallanvor shot her a smile as he entered. He took some of the cups from her arm, then both of them presented themselves before Perrin. Tallanvor bowed formally, which gave Morgase a stab of annoyance. He was still a member of the Queen's Guard - the only loyal member, as far as she knew.

hi ʃʊdn bi boʊɪŋ tə ðɪs ɹʊɹəl ʌpstɑɹt.

He shouldn't be bowing to this rural upstart.

"aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən ə sədʒɛstʃən bæk wən jə fɝs dʒɔɪn ʌs," pɛɹɪn sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "wɛl, aɪ θɪŋk ɪts əbaʊt taɪm aɪ tʊk ɪt. leɪtli, jə tu ɑɹ laɪk juðz fɹəm dɪfɹən vɪlədʒəz, munɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ði aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ sʌndeɪ ɛnz. ɪts haɪ taɪm jə wɝ mɛɹid. wi kəɾ əv æliændɝ də ɪt, əɹ meɪbi aɪ kʊd. juv səm tʃɹədɪʃən jə fɑloʊ?"

"I was given a suggestion back when you first joined us," Perrin said gruffly. "Well, I think it's about time I took it. Lately, you two are like youths from different villages, mooning over one another in the hour before Sunday ends. It's high time you were married. We could have Alliandre do it, or maybe I could. Do you have some tradition you follow?"

mɔɹɡeɪs blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. kɝs lini fəɹ pʊɾɪŋ ðəɾ aɪdiə ɪn pɝ-ɹɪnz hɛd! mɔɹɡeɪs fɛlt ə sʌɾən pænɪk, ðoʊ tɑlænvɝ ɡlænst əɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋli.

Morgase blinked in surprise. Curse Lini for putting that idea in Per-rin's head! Morgase felt a sudden panic, though Tallanvor glanced at her questioningly.

"ɡoʊ tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ naɪsɝ ɪf jə wɑnt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɡæðɝ ɛni jə wɑnə wɪtnəs ən bi bæk hɪɹ ɪn ən aʊɝ. ðən wɪl ɡɛt ðɪs sɪlinəs oʊvɝ wɪð."

"Go change into something nicer if you want," Perrin said. "Gather any you want to witness and be back here in an hour. Then we'll get this silliness over with."

ʃi fɛlt əɹ feɪs ɡɹoʊ hɑt wɪð æŋɡɝ. sɪlinəs? haʊ dɛɹ hi! ən ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ! sɛndɪŋ əɹ ɔf laɪk ə tʃaɪld, əz ɪf əɹ ɪmoʊʃən - hɝ lʌv - wɑz mɪɹli ən ɪnkənvinjəns tə hɪm?

She felt her face grow hot with anger. Silliness? How dare he! And in such a way! Sending her off like a child, as if her emotion - her love - was merely an inconvenience to him?

hi wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ ʌp ɪz mæp, bʌt ðən feɪlz hæn pleɪst ɑn ɪz ɑɹm kɑzd ɪm tə lʊk ʌp ən noʊɾəs ðəɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd nɑt bɪn fɑloʊd.

He was rolling up his map, but then Faile's hand placed on his arm caused him to look up and notice that his orders had not been followed.

"wɛl?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Well?" Perrin asked.

"noʊ," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. ʃi kɛpt əɹ ɡeɪz ɑn pɛɹɪn; ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə si ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl dɪsəpɔɪnmənt ən ɹɪdʒɛkʃən ɪn tɑlænvɝz feɪs.

"No," Morgase said. She kept her gaze on Perrin; she didn't want to see the inevitable disappointment and rejection in Tallanvor's face.

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What?" Perrin asked.

"noʊ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi bæk hɪɹ ɪn ən aʊɝ tə bi mɛɹid."

"No, Perrin Aybara," Morgase said. "I will not be back here in an hour to be married."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ɪf jə wɑn ti sɝvd, əɹ jəɹ tɛn klind, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ pækt, ðən kɔl fəɹ mi. ɪf jə wɪʃ jəɹ kloʊðɪŋ wɑʃt, əl əblaɪdʒ. bʌɾ aɪm jəɹ sɝvənt, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, nɑt jəɹ sʌbʒɪkt. aɪm lɔɪəl tə ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ. juv noʊ əθɔɹəɾi tə ɡɪmi ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə kəmænd."

"If you want tea served, or your tent cleaned, or something packed, then call for me. If you wish your clothing washed, I will oblige. But I am your servant, Perrin Aybara, not your subject. I am loyal to the Queen of Andor. You have no authority to give me this sort of command."

"aɪ-"

"I-"

"waɪ, ðə kwin hɝsɛlf wʊdn dɪmæn ðɪs! fɔɹsɪŋ tu pipəl tə mɛɹi kəz jəɹ taɪɝɾ ə ðə weɪ ðeɪ lʊk ət wʌn ənʌðɝ? laɪk tu haʊnz jə ɪntɛn tə bɹid, ðən sɛl ðə pʌps?"

"Why, the Queen herself wouldn't demand this! Forcing two people to marry because you're tired of the way they look at one another? Like two hounds you intend to breed, then sell the pups?"

"aɪ dɪdn min ɪt ðət weɪ."

"I didn't mean it that way."

"ju sɛɾ ɪt nʌnðəlɛs. bɪsaɪdz, haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ ə ðə jʌŋ mænz ɪntɛntʃənz? hæv jə spoʊkən tə hɪm, æsk hɪm, ɪntɝvjuɾ ɪm əz ə lɔɹd ʃəɾ ɪn ə mæɾɝ laɪk ðɪs?"

"You said it nonetheless. Besides, how can you be sure of the young man's intentions? Have you spoken to him, asked him, interviewed him as a lord should in a matter like this?"

"bʌt meɪaɪɡdɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "hi dʌz kɛɹ fəɹ ju. jə ʃʊɾə sin ðə weɪ hi æktəd wən jə wɝ teɪkən. laɪt, wʊmən, bʌɾ ɪts ɑbviəs!"

"But Maighdin," Perrin said. "He does care for you. You should have seen the way he acted when you were taken. Light, woman, but it's obvious!"

"mæɾɝz ə ðə hɑɹɾ ɑɹ nɛvɝ ɑbviəs." pʊlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp tə hɝ fʊl haɪt, ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛlt ə kwin əɡɛn. "ɪf aɪ tʃuz tə mɛɹi ə mæn, əl meɪk ðət dɪsɪʒən ɑn maɪ oʊn. fəɹ ə mæn u kleɪmz i dʌzn laɪk biɪŋ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, jə sɝɾənli də laɪk ɡɪvɪŋ kəmænz. haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ ðəɾ aɪ wɑn ðɪs jʌŋ mænz əfɛkʃənz? dʒju noʊ maɪ hɑɹt?"

"Matters of the heart are never obvious." Pulling herself up to her full height, she almost felt a queen again. "If I choose to marry a man, I will make that decision on my own. For a man who claims he doesn't like being in charge, you certainly do like giving commands. How can you be sure that I want this young man's affections? Do you know my heart?"

tə ðə saɪd, tɑlænvɝ stɪfənd. ðən i baʊd fɔɹməli tə pɛɹɪn ən stʃɹoʊd fɹəm ðə tɛnt. hi wɑz ən ɪmoʊʃənəl wʌn. wɛl, hi niɾəd tə noʊ ðət ʃi wəd nɑt bi ʃʌvd ɝaʊnd. nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ.

To the side, Tallanvor stiffened. Then he bowed formally to Perrin and strode from the tent. He was an emotional one. Well, he needed to know that she would not be shoved around. Not anymore.

fɝst ɡeɪbɹəl, ðən vɑldə, ən naʊ pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə? tɑlænvɝ wəd bi ɪl-sɝvd ɪf i wɝ tə ɹəsiv ə wʊmən u mɛɹiɾ ɪm kəz ʃi wɑz toʊl tə də soʊ.

First Gaebril, then valda, and now Perrin Aybara? Tallanvor would be ill-served if he were to receive a woman who married him because she was told to do so.

mɔɹɡeɪs mɛʒɝd pɛɹɪn, hu wɑz blʌʃɪŋ. ʃi sɔfən əɹ toʊn.

Morgase measured Perrin, who was blushing. She softened her tone.

"jɔɹ jʌŋ ət ðɪs jɛt, soʊ əl ɡɪv jə ædvaɪs. ðəɹ ɑɹ səm θɪŋz ə lɔɹd ʃəd bi ɪnvɑlvd ɪn, bʌɾ ʌðɝz i ʃəɾ ɔlweɪz liv əntʌtʃt.

"You're young at this yet, so I'll give you advice. There are some things a lord should be involved in, but others he should always leave untouched.

jəl lɝn ðə dɪfɝəns əz jə pɹæktəs, bʌt kaɪnli ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm meɪkɪŋ dɪmænz laɪk ðɪs wʌn əntɪl juv ət lis kaʊnsəld wɪð jəɹ waɪf."

You'll learn the difference as you practice, but kindly refrain from making demands like this one until you've at least counseled with your wife."

wɪð ðæt, ʃi kɝtsid - stɪl kæɹiɪŋ ðə tikəps - ən wɪθdʒɹu. ʃi ʃʊdn əv spoʊkən tə hɪm soʊ. wɛl, hi ʃʊdn əv meɪɾ ə kəmæn laɪk ðæt! ɪt simd ʃi hæd səm spɑɹk lɛft ɪn əɹ æftɝ ɔl. ʃi hædn fɛl ðət fɝm əɹ sɝɾən ə hɝsɛlf sɪns . . . wɛl, sɪns bɪfɔɹ ɡaɪ-bɹɪlz ɝaɪvəl ɪn keɪɛmlɪn! ðoʊ ʃi wəɾ əv tə faɪn tɑlænvɝ ən suð ɪz pɹaɪd.

With that, she curtsied - still carrying the teacups - and withdrew. She shouldn't have spoken to him so. Well, he shouldn't have made a command like that! It seemed she had some spark left in her after all. She hadn't felt that firm or certain of herself since . . . well, since before Gae-bril's arrival in Caemlyn! Though she would have to find Tallanvor and soothe his pride.

ʃi ɹɪtɝn ðə kʌps tə ðə nɪɹbaɪ wɑʃɪŋ steɪʃən, ðən wɛn θɹu ðə kæmp, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ tɑlænvɝ. ɝaʊn hɝ, sɝvəns ən wɝkɝz wɝ bɪzi ət ðɛɹ duɾiz. mɛni ʌv ðə fɔɹmɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn stɪl æktəɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ sʌmwʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz lʊkt ət ðɛm. ðoʊz fɹəm kɛɹhin wɝ ðə wɝst; ðeɪd bɪn hɛld lɔŋɡəst, ən il wɝ vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət titʃɪŋ lɛsənz.

She returned the cups to the nearby washing station, then went through the camp, looking for Tallanvor. Around her, servants and workers were busy at their duties. Many of the former gai'shain still acted as if they were among the Shaido, bowing and scraping whenever someone so much as looked at them. Those from Cairhien were the worst; they'd been held longest, and Aiel were very good at teaching lessons.

ðəɹ wɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, ə fju ɹil il ɡeɪʃeɪn. wʌɾ ən ɑd kʌstəm. fɹəm wʌt mɔɹɡeɪs hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə dətɝmən, səm ə ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn hɪɹ hæd bɪn teɪkən baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðən hæd bɪn lɪbɝeɪɾɪd ɪn meɪɾən. ðeɪ ɹɪteɪn ðə waɪt, ən soʊ ðət mɛn ðeɪ wɝ naʊ æktɪŋ əz sleɪvz tə ðɛɹ oʊn ɹɛləɾɪvz ən fɹɛnz.

There were, of course, a few real Aiel gai'shain. What an odd custom. From what Morgase had been able to determine, some of the gai'shain here had been taken by the Shaido, then had been liberated in Maiden. They retained the white, and so that meant they were now acting as slaves to their own relatives and friends.

ɛni pipəl kəd bi ʌndɝstʊd. bʌt, ʃi ədmɪɾəd, pɝhæps ði il wəd teɪk lɔŋɡɝ ðən ʌðɝz. teɪk, fəɹ ɪnstəns, ðət ɡɹup ə meɪɾənz ləpɪŋ θɹu kæmp. waɪ dɪd ðeɪv tə fɔɹs ɛvɹiwʌn aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ? ðəɹ wɑz noʊ -  mɔɹɡeɪs hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðoʊz meɪɾənz wɝ hɛɾɪŋ stʃɹeɪt fəɹ pɛɹɪnz tɛnt. ðeɪ lʊk laɪk ðeɪ hæd nuz.

Any people could be understood. But, she admitted, perhaps the Aiel would take longer than others. Take, for instance, that group of Maidens loping through camp. Why did they have to force everyone out of their way? There was no -  Morgase hesitated. Those Maidens were heading straight for Perrin's tent. They looked like they had news.

hɝ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə bɛɾɝ ə hɝ, mɔɹɡeɪs fɑloʊd. ðə meɪɾənz lɛf tu ɡɑɹdz baɪ ðə fɹʌn tɛn flæps, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ hæd bɪn ɹimuvd. mɔɹɡeɪs ɹaʊndəd ðə tɛnt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk əz ɪf ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, filɪŋ ə stæb ə ʃeɪm fəɹ livɪŋ tɑlænvɝ tə hɪz peɪn.

Her curiosity getting the better of her, Morgase followed. The Maidens left two guards by the front tent flaps, but the ward against eavesdropping had been removed. Morgase rounded the tent, trying to look as if she was doing anything other than eavesdropping, feeling a stab of shame for leaving Tallanvor to his pain.

"waɪtkloʊks, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," səlɪnz staʊt vɔɪs ɹipɔɹɾəd fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə lɑɹdʒ fɔɹs ə ðɛm ɑn ðə ɹoʊd dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌs."

"Whitecloaks, Perrin Aybara," Sulin's stout voice reported from inside. "There is a large force of them on the road directly in front of us."


tʃæptɝ sɛvən


CHAPTER 7

laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ


Lighter than a Feather

ði ɛɹ fɛl kɑmɝ ət naɪt, ðoʊ ðə θʌndɝ stɪl wɔɹn læn ðət nɑɾ ɔl wɑz wɛl. ɪn ɪz wiks tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð bʌlən, ðət stɔɹm əbʌv sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn dɑɹkɝ.

The air felt calmer at night, though the thunder still warned Lan that not all was well. In his weeks traveling with Bulen, that storm above seemed to have grown darker.

æftɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ saʊθwɝd, ðeɪ kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn tə ði ist; ðeɪ wɝ sʌmwɛɹ nɪɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝ bɪtwin kændɝ ən sɑldɑiə, ɑn ðə pleɪn ə lænsɪz. taʊɝɪŋ, wɛðɝd hɪlz - stip-saɪɾəd, laɪk fɔɹtʃɹəsəz - ɹoʊz ɝaʊn ðɛm.

After riding southward, they continued on to the east; they were somewhere near the border between Kandor and Saldaea, on the Plain of Lances. Towering, weathered hills - steep-sided, like fortresses - rose around them.

pɝhæps ðeɪd mɪs ðə bɔɹɾɝ. ðəɹ ɔfən wɑz noʊ mɑɹkɝ ɑn ðiz bæk ɹoʊdz, ən ðə maʊntənz kɛɹd nɑt wɪtʃ neɪʃən tʃɹaɪd tə kleɪm ðɛm.

Perhaps they'd missed the border. There often was no marker on these back roads, and the mountains cared not which nation tried to claim them.

"mæstɝ ænʒɹə," bʌlən sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. læn hæd pɝtʃəst ə hɔɹs fəɹ ɪm tə ɹaɪd, ə dʌsti waɪt mɛɹ. hi stɪl lɛɾ ɪz pækhɔɹs, skaʊɾɝ.

"Master Andra," Bulen said from behind. Lan had purchased a horse for him to ride, a dusty white mare. He still led his packhorse, Scouter.

bʌlən kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm. læn ɪnsɪstəɾ əpɑn biɪŋ kɔld "ænʒɹə." wʌn fɑloʊɝ wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf. ɪf noʊbɑdi nu hu hi wɑz, ðeɪ kʊdn æsk tə kʌm wɪð hɪm. hi hæd bʌlən tə θæŋk - ɪnədvɝɾəntli  - fəɹ ðə wɔɹnɪŋ ʌv wʌt nɪneɪiv hæd dʌn. fəɹ ðæt, hi oʊd ðə mæn ə dɛt.

Bulen caught up to him. Lan insisted upon being called "Andra." One follower was bad enough. If nobody knew who he was, they couldn't ask to come with him. He had Bulen to thank - inadvertently  - for the warning of what Nynaeve had done. For that, he owed the man a debt.

bʌlən dɪd laɪk tə tɔk, ðoʊ.

Bulen did like to talk, though.

'mæstɝ ænʒɹə," bʌlən kəntɪnjud. "ɪf aɪ meɪ sədʒɛst, wi kəd tɝn saʊθ ət ðə bɝn kɹɔsɹoʊdz, jɛs? aɪ noʊ ə weɪpɔɪn ɪn ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən ðət sɝvz ðə vɛɹi bɛs kweɪl. wi kəd tɝn istwɝɾ əɡɛn ɑn ðə ɹoʊd tə saʊθ mɛtlɝ. ə mʌtʃ iziɝ pæθ. maɪ kʌzən əz ə fɑɹm əlɔŋ ðət ɹoʊd - - kʌzən ɑn maɪ mʌðɝz saɪd, mæstɝ ænʒɹə - ən wi kəd - " "wi kəntɪnju ðɪs weɪ," læn sɛd.

'Master Andra," Bulen continued. "If I may suggest, we could turn south at the Berndt Crossroads, yes? I know a waypoint inn in that direction that serves the very best quail. We could turn eastward again on the road to South Mettler. A much easier path. My cousin has a farm along that road - - cousin on my mother's side, Master Andra - and we could - " "We continue this way," Lan said.

"bʌt saʊθ mɛtlɝ ɪz ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ɹoʊdweɪ!"

"But South Mettler is a much better roadway!"

"æn ðɛɹfɔɹ mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tʃɹævəl tu, bʌlən."

"And therefore much better traveled too, Bulen."

bʌlən saɪd, bʌt fɛl saɪlənt. ðə hædɔɹi lʊkt ɡʊɾ ɝaʊn ɪz hɛɾ ən i hæd pɹuvən sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli keɪpəbəl wɪð ðə sɔɹd. əz tæləntəɾ ə stuɾənt əz læn hæd sin ɪn ə waɪl.

Bulen sighed, but fell silent. The hadori looked good around his head and he had proven surprisingly capable with the sword. As talented a student as Lan had seen in a while.

ɪt wɑz dɑɹk - naɪt keɪm ɝli hɪɹ, kəz ə ðoʊz maʊntənz. kəmpɛɹd tə ði ɛɹiəz nɪɹ ðə blaɪt, ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ fɛl tʃɪli. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə læn hɪɹ wɑz fɛɹli wɛl pɑpjəleɪɾəd. ɪndid, əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ pæs ðə kɹɔsɹoʊdz ðeɪ ɝaɪvd əɾ ən ɪn, wɪndoʊz stɪl ɡloʊɪŋ wɪð laɪt.

It was dark - night came early here, because of those mountains. Compared to the areas near the Blight, it also felt chilly. Unfortunately, the land here was fairly well populated. Indeed, about an hour past the crossroads they arrived at an inn, windows still glowing with light.

bʌlən lʊk təwɔɹɾ ɪt lɔŋɪŋli, bʌt læn kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn. hi hæɾ əm tʃɹævlɪŋ ət naɪt, moʊsli.

Bulen looked toward it longingly, but Lan continued on. He had them traveling at night, mostly.

ðə bɛɾɝ tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ sin.

The better to keep from being seen.

ə tʃɹioʊ ʌv mɛn sæɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪn, smoʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ paɪps ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ðə pʌnʒənt smoʊk waʊn ɪn ði ɛɹ, pæs ði ɪnz wɪndoʊz. læn dɪdnt ɡɪv əm mʌtʃ kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən əntɪl - əz ə ɡɹup -  ðeɪ bɹoʊk ɔf ðɛɹ smoʊkɪŋ. ðeɪ ənhʊk hɔɹsəz fɹəm ðə fɛns ət ðə saɪɾ ə ði ɪn.

A trio of men sat in front of the inn, smoking their pipes in the darkness. The pungent smoke wound in the air, past the inns windows. Lan didn't give them much consideration until - as a group -  they broke off their smoking. They unhooked horses from the fence at the side of the inn.

wʌndɝfəl, læn θɔt. haɪweɪmɪn, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə naɪt ɹoʊd fəɹ wɪɹi tʃɹævəlɝz. wɛl, θɹi mɛn ʃʊdn pɹuv tu deɪnʒɝəs. ðeɪ ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn læn əɾ ə tʃɹɑt. ðeɪ wʊdn ətæk əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ði ɪn. læn ɹitʃt tə lusən ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts ʃiθ.

Wonderful, Lan thought. Highwaymen, watching the night road for weary travelers. Well, three men shouldn't prove too dangerous. They rode behind Lan at a trot. They wouldn't attack until they were farther from the inn. Lan reached to loosen his sword in its sheath.

"maɪ lɔɹd," bʌlən sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "tu ʌv ðoʊz mɛn ɑɹ wɛɹɪŋ ðə hædɔɹi'.'

"My Lord," Bulen said urgently, looking over his shoulder. "Two of those men are wearing the hadori'.'

læn spʌn ɝaʊnd, kloʊk wɪpɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðə θɹi mɛn əpɹoʊtʃt ən dɪd nɑt stɑp. ðeɪ splɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪm ən bʌlən.

Lan spun around, cloak whipping behind him. The three men approached and did not stop. They split around him and Bulen.

læn wɑtʃt əm pæs. "ændɪɹ?" hi kɔld. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jəɹ duɪŋ?"

Lan watched them pass. "Andere?" he called. "What do you think you're doing?"

wʌn ə ðə θɹi - ə lin, deɪnʒɝəs-lʊkɪŋ mæn - ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, hɪz lɔŋ hɛɹ hɛl bæk wɪð ðə hædɔɹi. ɪt hæd bɪn jɪɹz sɪns læn hæd sin ændɪɹ. hi lʊkt əz ɪf hid ɡɪvən ʌp ɪz kændɔɹi junəfɔɹm, faɪnəli; hi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə dip blæk kloʊk ən hʌntɪŋ lɛðɝz ʌndɝniθ.

One of the three - a lean, dangerous-looking man - glanced over his shoulder, his long hair held back with the hadori. It had been years since Lan had seen Andere. He looked as if he'd given up his Kandori uniform, finally; he was wearing a deep black cloak and hunting leathers underneath.

"ɑ, læn," ændɪɹ sɛd, ðə θɹi mɛn pʊlɪŋ ʌp tə stɑp. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊɾəs jə ðɛɹ."

"Ah, Lan," Andere said, the three men pulling up to stop. "I didn't notice you there."

"aɪm ʃʊɹ jə dɪdnt," læn sɛd flætli. 'æn ju, nɑzɑɹ. jə pʊt jəɹ hædɔɹi əweɪ wən jə wɝ ə læd. naʊ jə dɑn wʌn?"

"I'm sure you didn't," Lan said flatly. 'And you, Nazar. You put your hadori away when you were a lad. Now you don one?"

"aɪ meɪ də əz aɪ wɪʃ," nɑzɑɹ sɛd. hi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊld - hi mʌs bi pæst ɪz sɛvəntiɪθ jɪɹ - bʌɾ i kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl. hɪz hɛɹ hæd ɡɔn waɪt.

"I may do as I wish," Nazar said. He was getting old - he must be past his seventieth year - but he carried a sword on his saddle. His hair had gone white.

ðə θɝd mæn, ɹɑkim, wɑzn mɔlkɪɹi. hi hæd ðə tɪltəɾ aɪz ʌv ə sɑldəiən, ən i ʃɹʌɡd ət læn, lʊkɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɪmbɛɹəst.

The third man, Rakim, wasn't Malkieri. He had the tilted eyes of a Saldaean, and he shrugged at Lan, looking a little embarrassed.

læn ɹeɪzd ɪz fɪŋɡɝz tə hɪz fɔɹhɛd, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz əz ðə θɹi ɹoʊɾ əhɛd. wʌt fulɪʃ ɡeɪm wɝ ðeɪ pleɪɪŋ? noʊ mæɾɝ, læn θɔt, oʊpənɪŋ ɪz aɪz.

Lan raised his fingers to his forehead, closing his eyes as the three rode ahead. What foolish game were they playing? No matter, Lan thought, opening his eyes.

bʌlən stɑɹɾəd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt læn kwaɪəɾəd ɪm wɪð ə ɡlɛɹ. hi tɝn saʊθwɝɾ ɔf ðə ɹoʊd, kʌɾɪŋ daʊn ə smɔl, wɔɹn tʃɹeɪl.

Bulen started to say something, but Lan quieted him with a glare. He turned southward off the road, cutting down a small, worn trail.

bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, hi hɝd mʌfəl hʊfbits fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. læn spʌn əz i sɔ ðə θɹi mɛn ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. læn pʊl mændɑɹb tə ə hɔlt, tiθ ɡɹɪɾɪd. "aɪm nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn!"

Before long, he heard muffled hoofbeats from behind. Lan spun as he saw the three men riding behind him. Lan pulled Mandarb to a halt, teeth gritted. "I'm not raising the Golden Crane!"

"wi dɪdn seɪ jə wɝ," nɑzɑɹ sɛd. ðə θɹi pɑɹɾəd ɝaʊn ɪm əɡɛn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ pæst.

"We didn't say you were," Nazar said. The three parted around him again, riding past.

læn kɪk mændɑɹb fɔɹwɝd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðɛm. "ðɛn stɑp fɑloʊɪŋ mi."

Lan kicked Mandarb forward, riding up to them. "Then stop following me."

"læst aɪ tʃɛkt, wi wɝ əhɛɾ ə ju," ændɪɹ sɛd.

"Last I checked, we were ahead of you," Andere said.

"ju tɝn ðɪs weɪ æftɝ mi," læn əkjuzd.

"You turned this way after me," Lan accused.

"ju doʊn oʊn ðə ɹoʊdz, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən," ændɪɹ sɛd. hi ɡlænst ət læn, feɪs ʃæɾoʊd ɪn ðə naɪt. "ɪf jə hævənt noʊɾəst, ɪm noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðə bɔɪ ðə hɪɹoʊ ʌv sælmɑɹnə bɪɹeɪɾɪd soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. aɪv bɪkʌm ə soʊlʒɝ, ən soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ niɾəd. soʊ əl ɹaɪd ðɪs weɪ ɪf aɪ pliz."

"You don't own the roads, Lan Mandragoran," Andere said. He glanced at Lan, face shadowed in the night. "If you haven't noticed, I'm no longer the boy the Hero of Salmarna berated so long ago. I've become a soldier, and soldiers are needed. So I will ride this way if I please."

"aɪ kəmæn jə tə tɝn ən ɡoʊ bæk," læn sɛd. "faɪn ə dɪfɹən pæθ istwɝd."

"I command you to turn and go back," Lan said. "Find a different path eastward."

ɹɑkim læft, hɪz vɔɪs stɪl hɔɹs æftɝ ɔl ðiz jɪɹz. "jɔɹ nɑt maɪ kæptən ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, læn.

Rakim laughed, his voice still hoarse after all these years. "You're not my captain any longer, Lan.

waɪ wəɾ aɪ oʊbeɪ jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz?" ði ʌðɝz tʃʌkəld.

Why would I obey your orders?" The others chuckled.

"wiɾ oʊbeɪ ə kɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs," nɑzɑɹ sɛd.

"We'd obey a king, of course," Nazar said.

"jɛs," ændɪɹ sɛd. "ɪf i ɡeɪv əs kəmænz, pɝhæps wi wʊd. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si ə kɪŋ hɪɹ.

"Yes," Andere said. "If he gave us commands, perhaps we would. But I don't see a king here.

ənlɛs aɪm mɪsteɪkən."

Unless I'm mistaken."

"ðɛɹ kən bi noʊ kɪŋ ʌv ə fɔlən pipəl," læn sɛd. "noʊ kɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə kɪŋdəm."

"There can be no king of a fallen people," Lan said. "No king without a kingdom."

"æn jɛt jə ɹaɪd," nɑzɑɹ sɛd, flɪkɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz. "ɹaɪd tə jəɹ dɛθ ɪn ə læn jə kleɪm ɪz noʊ kɪŋdəm."

"And yet you ride," Nazar said, flicking his reins. "Ride to your death in a land you claim is no kingdom."

"ɪɾ ɪz maɪ dɛstəni."

"It is my destiny."

ðə θɹi ʃɹʌɡd, ðən pʊld əhɛɾ ə hɪm.

The three shrugged, then pulled ahead of him.

"doʊn bi fulz," læn sɛd, vɔɪs sɑft əz i pʊl mændɑɹb tə ə hɔlt. "ðɪs pæθ lidz tə dɛθ."

"Don't be fools," Lan said, voice soft as he pulled Mandarb to a halt. "This path leads to death."

"dɛθ ɪz laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən," ɹɑkim kɔld oʊvɝ "ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɪf wi ɹaɪɾ oʊnli tə dɛθ, ðən ðə tʃɹeɪl wɪl bi iziɝ ðən aɪd θɔt!"

"Death is lighter than a feather, Lan Mandragoran," Rakim called over "is shoulder. "If we ride only to death, then the trail will be easier than I'd thought!"

læn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, bʌt wʌt wɑz i tə du? biɾ ɔl θɹi ʌv əm sɛnsləs ən liv əm bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd? hi nʌdʒ mændɑɹb fɔɹwɝd.

Lan gritted his teeth, but what was he to do? Beat all three of them senseless and leave them beside the road? He nudged Mandarb forward.

ðə tu hæd bɪkʌm faɪv.

The two had become five.

* * * ɡɑləd kəntɪnjuɾ ɪz mɔɹnɪŋ mil, noʊɾɪŋ ðət tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ hæd kʌm tə spik wɪð hɪm. ðə mil wɑz sɪmpəl fɛɹ: pɔɹədʒ wɪð ə hændfʊl ə ɹeɪzənz stɝɾ ɪn. ə sɪmpəl mil fəɹ ɛvɹi soʊlʒɝ kɛpt əm ɔl fɹəm ɛnvi. səm lɔɹdz kæptən kəmændɝ hæd daɪn fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən ðɛɹ mɛn. ðət wəd nɑt də fəɹ ɡɑləd. nɑt wən soʊ mɛni ɪn ðə wɝl stɑɹvd.

* * * Galad continued his morning meal, noting that Child Byar had come to speak with him. The meal was simple fare: porridge with a handful of raisins stirred in. A simple meal for every soldier kept them all from envy. Some Lords Captain Commander had dined far better than their men. That would not do for Galad. Not when so many in the world starved.

tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ weɪɾəd ɪnsaɪd ðə flæps ʌv ɡɑlədz tɛnt, əweɪɾɪŋ ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən. ðə ɡɔnt, sʌŋkən- tʃik mæn wɔɹ ɪz waɪt kloʊk, ə tɑbɝɾ oʊvɝ meɪl ʌndɝniθ.

Child Byar waited inside the flaps of Galad's tent, awaiting recognition. The gaunt, sunken- cheeked man wore his white cloak, a tabard over mail underneath.

ɡɑləɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli sɛɾ əsaɪɾ ɪz spun ən nɑɾəd tə baɪɑɝ. ðə soʊlʒɝ stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðə teɪbəl ən weɪɾəd, stɪl əɾ ətɛnʃən. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɪlæbɹət fɝnɪʃɪŋz tə ɡɑlədz tɛnt. hɪz sɔɹd - vɑldəz sɔɹd - leɪ ɑn ðə pleɪn teɪbəl bɪhaɪn ɪz wʊɾən boʊl, slaɪtli dʒɹɔn. ðə hɛɹənz ɑn ðə bleɪd pikt aʊt fɹəm bɪniθ ðə skæbɝd, ən ðə pɑlɪʃt stil ɹəflɛktəd baɪɑɝz fɔɹm.

Galad eventually set aside his spoon and nodded to Byar. The soldier strode up to the table and waited, still at attention. There were no elaborate furnishings to Galad's tent. His sword - Valda's sword - lay on the plain table behind his wooden bowl, slightly drawn. The herons on the blade peeked out from beneath the scabbard, and the polished steel reflected Byar's form.

"spik," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"Speak," Galad said.

"aɪ hæv mɔɹ nuz əbaʊt ði ɑɹmi, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ nɪɹ wɛɹ ðə kæptɪvz sɛd ðeɪ wəd bi, ə fju deɪz fɹəm ʌs."

"I have more news about the army, my Lord Captain Commander," Byar said. "They are near where the captives said they would be, a few days from us."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. "ðeɪ flaɪ ðə flæɡ ʌv ɡildən?"

Galad nodded. "They fly the flag of Ghealdan?"

"əlɔŋsaɪd ðə flæɡ ʌv min." ðət fleɪm ə zil ɡlɪntɪɾ ɪn baɪɑɝz aɪz. "æn ðə wʊlfhɛd, ðoʊ ɹɪpɔɹts seɪ ðeɪ tʊk ðət daʊn leɪt jɛstɝdeɪ. ɡoʊldeɪniz ɪz ðɛɹ. əɹ skaʊts ɑɹ ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt."

"Alongside the flag of Mayene." That flame of zeal glinted in Byar's eyes. "And the wolfhead, though reports say they took that down late yesterday. Goldeneyes is there. Our scouts are sure of it."

"dɪɾ i ɹɪli kɪl bɔɹnhəlz fɑðɝ?"

"Did he really kill Bornhald's father?"

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. aɪ hæv ə fəmɪljɛɹəɾi wɪð ðɪs kɹitʃɝ. hi ən ɪz tʃɹups kʌm fɹəm ə pleɪs kɔl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

"Yes, my Lord Captain Commander. I have a familiarity with this creature. He and his troops come from a place called the Two Rivers."

"ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?" ɡɑləd sɛd. "kjʊɹiəs, haʊ ɔfən aɪ sim tə hɪɹ ə ðət pleɪs, ðiz deɪz. ɪz ðət nɑt wɛɹ ælθɹ ɪz fɹʌm?"

"The Two Rivers?" Galad said. "Curious, how often I seem to hear of that place, these days. Is that not where al'Thor is from?"

"soʊ ɪts sɛd," baɪɑɝ ɹɪplaɪd.

"So it is said," Byar replied.

ɡɑləd ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn. "ðeɪ ɡɹoʊ ɡʊd təbæk ðɛɹ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv nɑt hɝɾ ə ðɛm ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑɹmiz."

Galad rubbed his chin. "They grow good tabac there, Child Byar, but I have not heard of them growing armies."

"ɪɾ ɪz ə dɑɹk pleɪs, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld ən aɪ spɛn səm taɪm ðəɹ læs jɪɹ; ɪts fɛstɝɪŋ wɪð dɑɹkfɹɛnz."

"It is a dark place, my Lord Captain Commander. Child Bornhald and I spent some time there last year; it is festering with Darkfriends."

ɡɑləd saɪd. "ju saʊn laɪk ə kwɛstʃənɝ."

Galad sighed. "You sound like a Questioner."

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," baɪɑɝ ɝnəsli kəntɪnjud, "maɪ lɔɹd, pliz bɪliv mi. aɪm nɑt sɪmpli spɛkjəleɪɾɪŋ. ðɪs ɪz dɪfɹənt."

"My Lord Captain Commander," Byar earnestly continued, "my Lord, please believe me. I am not simply speculating. This is different."

ɡɑləd fɹaʊnd. ðən i dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹd ði ʌðɝ stul bɪsaɪɾ ɪz teɪbəl. baɪɑɝ tʊk ɪt.

Galad frowned. Then he gestured toward the other stool beside his table. Byar took it.

"ɪkspleɪn jɝsɛlf," ɡɑləd sɛd. "æn tɛl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə noʊ ʌv ðɪs pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz."

"Explain yourself," Galad said. "And tell me everything you know of this Perrin Goldeneyes."

pɛɹɪn kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə taɪm wən sɪmpəl bɹɛkfəsts ə bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz hæd sæɾəsfaɪd hɪm. ðət wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðə keɪs. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz du tə hɪz ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ðə wʊlvz, əɹ meɪbi hɪz teɪsts hæd tʃeɪnʒd oʊvɝ taɪm. ðiz deɪz i kɹeɪv mit, ɪspɛʃli ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. hi kʊdn ɔlweɪz əv ɪt, ən ðət wɑz faɪn. bʌt dʒɛnɝəli hi dɪdn əv tə æsk.

perrin could remember a time when simple breakfasts of bread and cheese had satisfied him. That was no longer the case. Perhaps it was due to his relationship with the wolves, or maybe his tastes had changed over time. These days he craved meat, especially in the morning. He couldn't always have it, and that was fine. But generally he didn't have to ask.

ðət wɑz ðə keɪs ðɪs deɪ. hid ɹɪzən, wɑʃt ɪz feɪs, ən faʊn ə sɝvən ɛntɝɪŋ wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ tʃɑp ə hæm, stimɪŋ ən sʌkjəlɪnt. noʊ binz, noʊ vɛdʒtəbəlz. noʊ ɡɹeɪvi. dʒʌs ðə hæm, ɹʌbd wɪð sɔlt ən sɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ, wɪð ə pɛɹ ə bɔɪld ɛɡz. ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən sɛɾ əm ɑn ɪz teɪbəl, ðən wɪθdʒɹu.

That was the case this day. He'd risen, washed his face, and found a servant entering with a large chop of ham, steaming and succulent. No beans, no vegetables. No gravy. Just the ham, rubbed with salt and seared over the fire, with a pair of boiled eggs. The serving woman set them on his table, then withdrew.

pɛɹɪn waɪpt ɪz hænz, kɹɔsɪŋ ðə ɹʌɡ ʌv ɪz tɛn ən teɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə hæmz sɛnt. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm fɛlt i ʃəd tɝn ɪɾ əweɪ, bʌɾ i kʊdnt. nɑt wən ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt ðɛɹ. hi sæt daʊn, tʊk ʌp fɔɹk ən naɪf ən dʌɡ ɪn.

Perrin wiped his hands, crossing the rug of his tent and taking in the ham's scent. Part of him felt he should turn it away, but he couldn't. Not when it was right there. He sat down, took up fork and knife and dug in.

"aɪ stɪl doʊn si haʊ jə kən it ðət fəɹ bɹɛkfəst" feɪl noʊɾəd, livɪŋ ðə wɑʃɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ ə ðɛɹ tɛnt, waɪpɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn ə klɔθ. ðɛɹ lɑɹdʒ tɛn hæd sɛvɹəl kɝteɪn dɪvɪʒənz tə ɪt. ʃi wɔɹ wʌn ə hɝ ʌnəbtʃɹusɪv ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛsəz. pɝfəkt, kəz ɪt dɪdn dɪstʃɹæk fɹəm əɹ bjuɾi. ɪt wɑz æksɛntɪd baɪ ə stɝɾi blæk bɛlt - ʃi hæd sɛn əweɪ ɔl ə hɝ ɡoʊldən bɛls, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ faɪn. hid sədʒɛstəd faɪndɪŋ əɹ wʌn ðət wɑz mɔɹ tə hɝ laɪkɪŋ, ən ʃid lʊk sɪk.

"I still don't see how you can eat that for breakfast" Faile noted, leaving the washing chamber of their tent, wiping her hands on a cloth. Their large tent had several curtained divisions to it. She wore one of her unobtrusive gray dresses. Perfect, because it didn't distract from her beauty. It was accented by a sturdy black belt - she had sent away all of her golden belts, no matter how fine. He'd suggested finding her one that was more to her liking, and she'd looked sick.

"ɪts fud," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"It's food," Perrin said.

"aɪ kən si," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə snɔɹt, lʊkɪŋ hɝsɛlf oʊvɝ ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ. "wʌt dɪd jə θɪŋk aɪ əsumd ɪt wɑz? ə ɹɑk?"

"I can see," she said with a snort, looking herself over in the mirror. "What did you think I assumed it was? A rock?"

"aɪ mɛnt," pɛɹɪn sɛd bɪtwin baɪts, "ðæt fuɾ ɪz fud. waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ kɛɹ wʌɾ aɪ it fəɹ bɹɛkfəst ən wʌɾ aɪ it fəɹ ə dɪfɹən mil?"

"I meant," Perrin said between bites, "that food is food. Why should I care what I eat for breakfast and what I eat for a different meal?"

"bɪkɔz ɪts stʃɹeɪnʒ," ʃi sɛd, klæspɪŋ ɑn ə kɔɹd hoʊldɪŋ ə smɔl blu stoʊn. ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ, ðən tɝnd, ðə lus slivz ə hɝ sɑldəiən-kʌt dʒɹɛs swɪʃɪŋ. ʃi pɔz bɪsaɪɾ ɪz pleɪt, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "aɪm hævɪŋ bɹɛkfəst wɪð ɔiɑndɝ. sɛn fəɹ mi ɪf ðəɹ ɪz nuz."

"Because it's strange," she said, clasping on a cord holding a small blue stone. She regarded herself in the mirror, then turned, the loose sleeves of her Saldaean-cut dress swishing. She paused beside his plate, grimacing. "I'm having breakfast with AUiandre. Send for me if there is news."

hi nɑɾəd, swɑloʊɪŋ. waɪ ʃəɾ ə pɝsən əv miɾ ət mɪddeɪ, bʌt ɹəfjuz ɪt fəɹ bɹɛkfəst? ɪt dɪdn meɪk sɛns.

He nodded, swallowing. Why should a person have meat at midday, but refuse it for breakfast? It didn't make sense.

hid dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɹɪmeɪn kæmp bɪsaɪd ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd. wʌɾ ɛls wɑz i tə du, wɪð ən ɑɹmi ʌv waɪtkloʊks dɝɛkli əhɛd, bɪtwin ɪm ən luɡɹd? hɪz skaʊts niɾəd taɪm tə əsɛs ðə deɪnʒɝ.

He'd decided to remain camped beside the Jehannah Road. What else was he to do, with an army of Whitecloaks directly ahead, between him and Lugard? His scouts needed time to assess the danger.

hid spɛn mʌtʃ taɪm θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ vɪʒənz hid sin, ðə wʊlvz tʃeɪsɪŋ ʃip təwɔɹɾ ə bist ən feɪl wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə klɪf. hi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk sɛns ə ðɛm, bʌt kəd ðeɪv sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks? ðɛɹ əpɪɹəns bɑðɝɾ ɪm mɔɹ ðən i wɑntəd tə ədmɪt, bʌɾ i hɑɹbɝɾ ə taɪni hoʊp ðət ðeɪ wəd pɹuv ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkən ən nɑt sloʊ hɪm tu mʌtʃ.

He'd spent much time thinking about the strange visions he'd seen, the wolves chasing sheep toward a beast and Faile walking toward a cliff. He hadn't been able to make sense of them, but could they have something to do with the Whitecloaks? Their appearance bothered him more than he wanted to admit, but he harbored a tiny hope that they would prove insignificant and not slow him too much.

"pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ə vɔɪs kɔl fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz tɛnt. "du jə ɡɪmi liv tə ɛntɝ?"

"Perrin Aybara," a voice called from outside his tent. "Do you give me leave to enter?"

"kʌm ɪn, ɡɔl," hi kɔld. "maɪ ʃeɪɾ ɪz jʊɹz."

"Come in, Gaul," he called. "My shade is yours."

ðə tɔl il stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn. "θæŋk ju, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," hi sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə hæm. "kwaɪɾ ə fist.

The tall Aiel strode in. "Thank you, Perrin Aybara," he said, glancing at the ham. "Quite a feast.

dʒju sɛləbɹeɪt?"

Do you celebrate?"

"nʌθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz bɹɛkfəst."

"Nothing besides breakfast."

"ə maɪɾi vɪktɝi," ɡɔl sɛd, læfɪŋ.

"A mighty victory," Gaul said, laughing.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. il hjumɝ. hid stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk sɛns ʌv ɪt. ɡɔl sɛɾəld hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən pɛɹɪn saɪɾ ɪnwɝdli bɪfɔɹ pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz pleɪɾ ən muvɪŋ tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə ɹʌɡ əkɹɔs fɹəm ɡɔl. pɛɹɪn pleɪs ðə mil ɪn ɪz læp ən kəntɪnjud tə it.

Perrin shook his head. Aiel humor. He'd stopped trying to make sense of it. Gaul settled himself on the ground and Perrin sighed inwardly before picking up his plate and moving to sit on the rug across from Gaul. Perrin placed the meal in his lap and continued to eat.

"ju nid nɑt sɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ kəz ə mi," ɡɔl sɛd.

"You need not sit on the floor because of me," Gaul said.

"aɪm nɑt duɪŋ ɪt kəz aɪ nid tə, ɡɔl."

"I'm not doing it because I need to, Gaul."

ɡɔl nɑɾəd.

Gaul nodded.

pɛɹɪn kʌɾ ɔf ənʌðɝ baɪt. ðɪs wəd bi soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ ɪf i ɡɹæb ðə hoʊl θɪŋ ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən stɑɹɾəd ɹɪpɪŋ ɔf tʃʌŋks. iɾɪŋ wɑz sɪmpəlɝ fəɹ wʊlvz. jutɛnsəlz. wʌt wɑz ðə pɔɪnt?

Perrin cut off another bite. This would be so much easier if he grabbed the whole thing in his fingers and started ripping off chunks. Eating was simpler for wolves. Utensils. What was the point?

θɔts laɪk ðət ɡeɪv ɪm pɔz. hi wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊlf, ən dɪdnt wɑnə θɪŋk laɪk wʌn. meɪbi hi ʃəd stɑɹt hævɪŋ fɹut fəɹ ə pɹɑpɝ bɹɛkfəst, əz feɪl sɛd. hi fɹaʊnd, ðən tɝn bæk tə hɪz mit.

Thoughts like that gave him pause. He was not a wolf, and didn't want to think like one. Maybe he should start having fruit for a proper breakfast, as Faile said. He frowned, then turned back to his meat.

"wi fɔt tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," baɪɑɝ sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs. ɡɑlədz pɔɹədʒ kuld, fɝɡɑɾən ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "sɛvɹəl dʌzən mɛn ɪn əɹ kæmp kən kənfɝm ɪt. aɪ kɪl sɛvɹəl ə ðə bists wɪð maɪ oʊn sɔɹd."

"We fought Trollocs in the Two Rivers," Byar said, lowering his voice. Galad's porridge cooled, forgotten on the table. "Several dozen men in our camp can confirm it. I killed several of the beasts with my own sword."

"tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?" ɡɑləd sɛd. "ðæts hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz!"

"Trollocs in the Two Rivers?" Galad said. "That's hundreds of leagues from the Borderlands!"

"ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ nʌnðəlɛs," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ naɪl mʌst əv səspɛktəɾ ɪt. wi wɝ sɛn tə ðə pleɪs ɑn ɪz ɔɹɾɝz. jə noʊ ðət peɪdʒɹən naɪl wəd nɑɾ əv sɪmpli dʒʌmpt ət nʌθɪŋ."

"They were there nonetheless," Byar said. "Lord Captain Commander Niall must have suspected it. We were sent to the place on his orders. You know that Pedron Niall would not have simply jumped at nothing."

"jɛs. aɪ əɡɹi. bʌt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?"

"Yes. I agree. But the Two Rivers?"

"ɪɾ ɪz fʊl ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "bɔɹnhəl toʊl jə ʌv ɡoʊldən-aɪz. ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðɪs pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə wɑz ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə flæɡ ʌv eɪntʃən meɪnɛðɝən ən ɡæðɝɪŋ ən ɑɹmi fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə fɑɹmɝz. tʃɹeɪn soʊlʒɝz meɪ skɔf ət fɑɹmɝz pɹɛst ɪndə sɝvəs, bʌt ɡɛɾ ɪnʌf ə ðɛm təɡɛðɝ, ən ðeɪ kən bi ə deɪnʒɝ. səm ɑɹ skɪld wɪð ðə stæf əɹ ðə baʊ."

"It is full of Darkfriends," Byar said. "Bornhald told you of Golden-eyes. In the Two Rivers, this Perrin Aybara was raising the flag of ancient Manetheren and gathering an army from among the farmers. Trained soldiers may scoff at farmers pressed into service, but get enough of them together, and they can be a danger. Some are skilled with the staff or the bow."

"aɪ æm əwɛɹ," ɡɑləd sɛd flætli, ɹɪkɔlɪŋ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ lɛsən hid wʌns bɪn ɡɪvən.

"I am aware," Galad said flatly, recalling a particularly embarrassing lesson he'd once been given.

"ðæt mæn, ðɪs pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," baɪɑɝ kəntɪnjud. "hiz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, əz pleɪn əz deɪ. ðeɪ kɔl ɪm ɡoʊldeɪniz kəz ɪz aɪz ɑɹ ɡoʊldən, noʊ ʃeɪd ðəɾ ɛni pɝsən əz ɛvɝ noʊn. wi wɝ sɝɾən ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə wɑz bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks ɪn, juzɪŋ əm tə fɔɹs ðə pipəl ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz tə dʒɔɪn ɪz ɑɹmi. hi ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹæn əs aʊɾ ə ðə pleɪs. naʊ hiz hɪɹ, bɪfɔɹ ʌs." ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ?

"That man, this Perrin Aybara," Byar continued. "He's Shadowspawn, as plain as day. They call him Goldeneyes because his eyes are golden, no shade that any person has ever known. We were certain that Aybara was bringing the Trollocs in, using them to force the people of the Two Rivers to join his army. He eventually ran us out of the place. Now he's here, before us." A coincidence, or something more?

baɪɑɝ wɑz ɑbviəsli θɪŋkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə seɪm laɪnz. "maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, pɝhæps aɪ ʃʊɾə mɛnʃən ðɪs ɝliɝ, bʌt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑzn maɪ fɝst ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ðɪs kɹitʃɝ eɪbɑɹə. hi kɪl tu ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɑn ə fɝɡɑɾən ɹoʊɾ ɪn ændɝ səm tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ. aɪ wɑz tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð bɔɹnhəlz fɑðɝ. wi mɛɾ eɪbɑɹə ɪn ə kæmpsaɪɾ ɔf ə meɪn ɹoʊd. hi wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð wʊlvz laɪk ə waɪlmən! hi kɪl tu mɛn bɪfɔɹ wi kəd səbdu hɪm, ðən ɪskeɪpt ɪndə ðə naɪɾ æftɝ wi hæɾ ɪm kæptʃɝd. maɪ lɔɹd, hi wɑz tə bi hæŋd."

Byar was obviously thinking along the same lines. "My Lord Captain Commander, perhaps I should have mentioned this earlier, but the Two Rivers wasn't my first experience with this creature Aybara. He killed two of the Children on a forgotten road in Andor some two years ago. I was traveling with Bornhald's father. We met Aybara in a campsite off a main road. He was running with wolves like a wildman! He killed two men before we could subdue him, then escaped into the night after we had him captured. My Lord, he was to be hanged."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz u kən kənfɝm ðɪs?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

"There are others who can confirm this?" Galad asked.

"tʃaɪld ɔɹæɾɝ kæn. ən tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəl kən kənfɝm wʌt wi sɔ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɡoʊldeɪniz wɑz ət fɑlm, tu. fəɹ wʌɾ i dɪd ðəɹ əloʊn i ʃəd bi bɹɔt tə dʒʌstəs. ɪts klɪɹ. ðə laɪɾ əz dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪm tə ʌs."

"Child Oratar can. And Child Bornhald can confirm what we saw in the Two Rivers. Goldeneyes was at Falme, too. For what he did there alone he should be brought to justice. It is clear. The Light has delivered him to us."

"jɔɹ sɝɾən əɹ pipəl ɑɹ əmʌŋ ðə waɪtkloʊks?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You're certain our people are among the Whitecloaks?" Perrin asked.

"aɪ kəd nɑt si feɪsəz," ɡɔl sɛd, "bʌɾ ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹəz aɪz ɑɹ vɛɹi kin. hi sɛz hiz sɝɾən i sɔ bɑzəl ɡɪl."

"I could not see faces," Gaul said, "but Elyas Machera's eyes are very keen. He says he's certain he saw Basel Gill."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. ɛlaɪəs' ɡoʊldən aɪz wəd bi əz ɡʊɾ əz pɛɹɪnz oʊn.

Perrin nodded. Elyas' golden eyes would be as good as Perrin's own.

"səlɪn ən əɹ skaʊts əv sɪməlɝ ɹɪpɔɹts," ɡɔl sɛd, æksɛptɪŋ ə kʌp ʌv eɪl pɔɹd fɹəm pɛɹɪnz pɪtʃɝ. "ðə waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi hæz ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə kɑɹts, mʌtʃ laɪk ðə wʌnz wi sɛn əhɛd.

"Sulin and her scouts have similar reports," Gaul said, accepting a cup of ale poured from Perrin's pitcher. "The Whitecloak army has a large number of carts, much like the ones we sent ahead.

ʃi dɪskʌvɝd ðɪs ɝli ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ æsk mi tə pæs ðiz wɝdz tə jə wʌns jə əwoʊk, əz ʃi noʊz ðət wɛtləndɝz ɑɹ tɛmpɹəmɛntəl wən dɪstɝbd ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

She discovered this early in the morning, but asked me to pass these words to you once you awoke, as she knows that wetlanders are temperamental when disturbed in the morning."

ɡɔl ɑbviəsli hæd noʊ aɪdiə ðəɾ i maɪt bi ɡɪvɪŋ əfɛns. pɛɹɪn wɑz ə wɛtləndɝ. wɛtləndɝz wɝ tɛmpɹəmɛntəl, ət list ɪn ði əpɪnjən ə ði il. soʊ ɡɔl wɑz steɪɾɪŋ ən æksɛptɪd fækt. pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ wʌn ə ði ɛɡz. oʊvɝkʊkt, bʌɾ ɛɾəbəl. "dɪd səlɪn spɑɾ ɛniwʌn ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd?"

Gaul obviously had no idea that he might be giving offense. Perrin was a wetlander. Wetlanders were temperamental, at least in the opinion of the Aiel. So Gaul was stating an accepted fact. Perrin shook his head, trying one of the eggs. Overcooked, but edible. "Did Sulin spot anyone she recognized?"

"noʊ, ðoʊ ʃi sɔ səm ɡeɪʃeɪn" ɡɔl sɛd. "haʊɛvɝ, səlɪn ɪz ə meɪɾən, soʊ pɝhæps wi ʃəd sɛn sʌmwʌn tə kənfɝm wʌt ʃi sɛd -  sʌmwʌn u woʊn dɪmæn ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə wɑʃ əɹ smɔlkloʊðz."

"No, though she saw some gai'shain" Gaul said. "However, Sulin is a Maiden, so perhaps we should send someone to confirm what she said -  someone who won't demand the opportunity to wash our smallclothes."

"tʃɹʌbəl wɪð beɪn ən kiæd?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Trouble with Bain and Chiad?" Perrin asked.

ɡɔl ɡɹɪməst. "aɪ swɛɹ, ðoʊz wɪmən wɪl dʒɹaɪv ðə maɪn fɹəm mi. wʌt mæn ʃəd bi ɪkspɛktəd tə sʌfɝ sətʃ θɪŋz? ɔlmoʊs bɛɾɝ tə hæv saɪtblɪndɝ hɪmsɛlf əz ə ɡeɪʃeɪn ðən ðoʊz tu."

Gaul grimaced. "I swear, those women will drive the mind from me. What man should be expected to suffer such things? Almost better to have Sightblinder himself as a gai'shain than those two."

pɛɹɪn tʃʌkəld.

Perrin chuckled.

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs, ðə kæptɪvz lʊk ənhɑɹmd ən hɛlθi. ðəɹ ɪz mɔɹ tə ðə ɹipɔɹt. wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz sɔ ə flæɡ flaɪɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kæmp ðət lʊk dɪstɪŋktɪv, soʊ ʃi kɑpiɾ ɪt daʊn fəɹ jəɹ sɛkɹətɛɹi, sɛbæn beɪlwɝ. hi sɛz ðəɾ ɪt minz ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ hɪmsɛlf ɹaɪdz wɪð ðɪs ɑɹmi."

"Regardless, the captives look unharmed and healthy. There is more to the report. One of the Maidens saw a flag flying over the camp that looked distinctive, so she copied it down for your secretary, Sebban Balwer. He says that it means the Lord Captain Commander himself rides with this army."

pɛɹɪn lʊk daʊn ət ðə læs tʃʌŋk ə hæm. ðət wɑz nɑt ɡʊd nuz. hid nɛvɝ mɛt ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, bʌɾ i bæd mɛt wʌn ə ðə waɪtkloʊk lɔɹdz kæptən wʌns. ðət hæd bɪn ðə naɪt wən hɑpɝ hæd daɪd, ə naɪt ðət hæd hɔntəd pɛɹɪn fəɹ tu jɪɹz.

Perrin looked down at the last chunk of ham. That was not good news. He'd never met the Lord Captain Commander, but he bad met one of the Whitecloak Lords Captain once. That had been the night when Hopper had died, a night that had haunted Perrin for two years.

ðət hæd bɪn ðə naɪt wən i hæd kɪl fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm.

That had been the night when he had killed for the first time.

"No," Galad said. "No, by the Light, if what you say is true then we cannot turn our backs on this man. Our duty is to bring justice to the wronged."

baɪɑɝ smaɪld, lʊkɪŋ iɡɝ. "ðə pɹɪznɝz ɹɪvil ðət ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən əz swɔɹn fiəlti tə hɪm."

Byar smiled, looking eager. "The prisoners revealed that the Queen of Ghealdan has sworn fealty to him."

You speak of the Last Battle, but it could be months away. What if we were to free an entire nation from the grip of a terrible Darkfriend? Surely the Queen - or her successor - would feel indebted to us."

"əsumɪŋ wi kən dɪfit ðɪs eɪbɑɹə."

wɑz ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə biɪŋ tɑvɝən? kəd pɛɹɪn nɑɾ ɪskeɪp ðət naɪt, jɪɹz əɡoʊ? hi sɛɾ ɪz pleɪɾ əsaɪd, filɪŋ sɪk.

Was this part of being ta'veren? Could Perrin not escape that night, years ago? He set his plate aside, feeling sick.

"ɑɹ jə wɛl, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?" ɡɔl sɛd.

"dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ." ðə waɪtkloʊks wəd nɑt liv ɪm əloʊn, ən ðə pæɾɝn - bɝn ɪt! - wɑz gɑnə kip lupɪŋ əm ɪndə hɪz pæθ əntɪl i dɛlt wɪð ðɛm.

"There are twenty thousand soldiers among them," Gaul replied. "There are several thousand others who have likely never held a spear."

sɝvəns ən kæmp fɑloʊɝz. ɡɔl kɛp ði əmjuzmən fɹəm ɪz vɔɪs, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd smɛl ɪɾ ɑn hɪm. əmʌŋ ði il, nɪɹli ɛvɹi mæn - ɔl bʌt blæksmɪθs - wəd pɪk ʌp ə spɪɹ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ətækt. ðə fæk ðət mɛni wɛtləndɝz wɝ ɪnkeɪpəbəl ə dɪfɛndɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz iðɝ bɪfʌɾəld əɹ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd ði il.

Servants and camp followers. Gaul kept the amusement from his voice, but Perrin could smell it on him. Among the Aiel, nearly every man - all but blacksmiths - would pick up a spear if they were attacked. The fact that many wetlanders were incapable of defending themselves either befuddled or infuriated the Aiel.

"ðɛɹ fɔɹs ɪz lɑɹdʒ," ɡɔl kəntɪnjud, "bʌɾ aʊɝz ɪz lɑɹdʒɝ. ən ðeɪv noʊ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ nɔɹ æʃəmən, nɔɹ tʃænlɝz ʌv ɛni taɪp, ɪf sɛbæn beɪlwɝz wɝɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪn ɛɹɝ. hi simz tə noʊ mʌtʃ ə ðiz waɪt-kloʊks."

"Their force is large," Gaul continued, "but ours is larger. And they have no algai'd'siswai nor Asha'man, nor channelers of any type, if Sebban Balwer's word is not in error. He seems to know much of these White-cloaks."

"hiz ɹaɪt. waɪtkloʊks heɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən θɪŋk ɛniwʌn u kən juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"He's right. Whitecloaks hate Aes Sedai and think anyone who can use the One Power is a Darkfriend."

"wi muv əɡɛns hɪm, ðɛn?" baɪɑɝ æskt.

"We move against him, then?" Byar asked.

ɡɑləd stʊd. "wi hæv noʊ tʃɔɪs. ðə laɪɾ əz dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪm ɪndə əɹ hænz. bʌt wi nid mɔɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. pɝhæps aɪ ʃəd ɡoʊ tə ðɪs eɪbɑɹə ən lɛɾ ɪm noʊ ðət wi hoʊld ɪz ælaɪz, ən ðən æsk ɪz ɑɹmi tə mit wɪð əs ɑn ðə fild ə bæɾəl. aɪd ɹæðɝ dʒɹɔ hɪm aʊt tə meɪk jus ə maɪ kævəlɹi."

Galad stood. "We have no choice. The Light has delivered him into our hands. But we need more information. Perhaps I should go to this Aybara and let him know that we hold his allies, and then ask his army to meet with us on the field of battle. I'd rather draw him out to make use of my cavalry."

"wʌt dʒju wɑnt, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?" ɡɔl æskt.

"What do you want, Perrin Aybara?" Gaul asked.

wʌɾ i wɑnt? hi wɪʃt i kəɾ ænsɝ ðæt.

What did he want? He wished he could answer that.

sɛn mɔɹ skaʊts," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "faɪn əs ə bɛɾɝ pleɪs tə kæmp. wɪl wɑnə ɔfɝ pɑɹli, bʌt ðəɹ ɛs noʊ weɪ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ aɪm livɪŋ. ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə waɪɾitʃoʊks. wɪl ɡɪv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən tʃæns tə ɹɪtɝn əɹ pipəl. ɪf ðeɪ doʊnt. . . wɛl, ðən wɪl si "

Send more scouts," Perrin said. "Find us a better place to camp. We'll want to offer parley, but there s no way under the Light I'm leaving. Gill and the others in the hands of the Whitecioaks. We'll give the Children chance to return our people. If they don't. . . well, then we'll see "


tʃæptɝ eɪt


CHAPTER 8

ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp læs


The Seven-Striped Lass

mæt sæɾ ɑn ə wɔɹn stul, hɪz ɑɹmz linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə dɑɹk wʊɾən bɑɹ kaʊntɝ. ði ɛɹ smɛld ɡʊd - ʌv eɪl, smoʊk, ən ə ðə wɑʃklɔθ ðət hæd ɹisənli waɪp ðə kaʊntɝ. hi laɪk ðæt. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ kɑmɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə ɡʊd, ɹaʊɾi tævɝn ðət wɑz ɔlsoʊ kɛp klin. wɛl, klin əz wɑz ɹizənəbəl, ɛniweɪ. noʊbɑdi laɪkt ə tævɝn ðət wɑz tu klin. ðət meɪɾ ə pleɪs fil nu. laɪk ə koʊt ðət hæd nɛvɝ bɪn wɔɹn əɹ ə paɪp ðət hæd nɛvɝ bɪn smoʊkt.

Mat sat on a worn stool, his arms leaning against a dark wooden bar counter. The air smelled good - of ale, smoke, and of the washcloth that had recently wiped the counter. He liked that. There was something calming about a good, rowdy tavern that was also kept clean. Well, clean as was reasonable, anyway. Nobody liked a tavern that was too clean. That made a place feel new. Like a coat that had never been worn or a pipe that had never been smoked.

mæt flɪpt ə foʊldəd lɛɾɝ bɪtwin tu fɪŋɡɝz ə hɪz ɹaɪt hænd. ðət lɛɾɝ, ɑn θɪk peɪpɝ, wɑz sild wɪð ə ɡlɑb ə blʌd-ɹɛd wæks. hi hæd bɪn kæɹiɪŋ ɪɾ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ə sɔɹs ʌv əz mʌtʃ æɡɹəveɪʃən tə hɪm əz ɛni wʊmən. wɛl, meɪbi nɑɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt moʊst ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən. ðət wɑz seɪɪŋ ə lɑt.

Mat flipped a folded letter between two fingers of his right hand. That letter, on thick paper, was sealed with a glob of blood-red wax. He had been carrying it only a short time, but it was already a source of as much aggravation to him as any woman. Well, maybe not an Aes Sedai, but most any other woman. That was saying a lot.

hi stɑp spɪnɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ ən tæpt ɪɾ ɑn ðə kaʊntɝ. bɝn vɛɹɪn fəɹ duɪŋ ðɪs tə hɪm! ʃi hɛld ɪm baɪ hɪz oʊθ laɪk ə fɪʃ kɑɾ ɑn ə hʊk.

He stopped spinning the letter and tapped it on the counter. Burn Verin for doing this to him! She held him by his oath like a fish caught on a hook.

wɛl, mæstɝ kɹɪmzən?" æsk ðə tɑvɝŋkipɝ. ðət wɑz ðə neɪm i wɑz juzɪŋ ðiz deɪz. bɛs tə bi seɪf. "ju wɑn ə ɹifɪl əɹ nɑt?"

Well, Master Crimson?" asked the tavernkeeper. That was the name he was using these days. Best to be safe. "You want a refill or not?"

ðə tɑvɝŋkipɝ lin daʊn bɪfɔɹ hɪm, kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. mɛli kɹɛb wɑz ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən, wɪð ə ɹaʊn feɪs ən ɑbɝn hɛɹ ðət kɝl kwaɪt fɛtʃəŋli. mæt wʊɾə ɡɪvən əɹ ɪz bɛst smaɪl - ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən i hæd mɛɾ u dɪd nɑt mɛl fəɹ ɪz bɛst smaɪl - bʌɾ i wɑz ə mɛɹid mæn naʊ. hi kəd nɑt ɡoʊ bɹeɪkɪŋ hɑɹts; ɪt wəd nɑt bi ɹaɪt.

The tavernkeeper leaned down before him, crossing her arms. Melli Craeb was a pretty woman, with a round face and auburn hair that curled quite fetchingly. Mat would have given her his best smile - there was not a woman he had met who did not melt for his best smile - but he was a married man now. He could not go breaking hearts; it would not be right.

ðoʊ, linɪŋ əz ʃi dɪd ʃoʊd səm æmpəl bʊzəm. ʃi wɑz ə ʃɔɹt wʊmən, bʌt ʃi kɛp ði ɛɹiə bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹ ɹeɪzd. jɛs, ə naɪs bʊzəm ɪndid. hi fɪɡjɝd ʃi wəd bi ɡʊd fəɹ ə bɪɾ ə kɪsɪŋ, pɝhæps tʌkt ɪndə wʌn ə ðə buθs ət ðə bæk ə ðə tævɝn. ʌv kɔɹs, mæt dɪd nɑt lʊk ət wɪmən ɛnimɔɹ, nɑt laɪk ðæt. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk əbaʊɾ əɹ fəɹ ɪm tə kɪs. meɪbi fəɹ tælmɑnz. hi wɑz soʊ stɪf, ə ɡʊd kɪs ən kʌɾəl wəd də hɪm ɡʊd.

Though, leaning as she did showed some ample bosom. She was a short woman, but she kept the area behind the bar raised. Yes, a nice bosom indeed. He figured she would be good for a bit of kissing, perhaps tucked into one of the booths at the back of the tavern. Of course, Mat did not look at women anymore, not like that. He did not think about her for him to kiss. Maybe for Talmanes. He was so stiff, a good kiss and cuddle would do him good.

"wɛl?" mɛli æskt.

"Well?" Melli asked.

"wʌt wəd jə də ɪf jə wɝ mi, mɛli?" hɪz ɛmpti mʌɡ sæt bɪsaɪd hɪm, ə fju sʌdz klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə ɹɪm.

"What would you do if you were me, Melli?" His empty mug sat beside him, a few suds clinging to the rim.

"ɔɹɾɝ ənʌðɝ ɹaʊnd," ʃi sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "fɔɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ bɑɹ. ɪt wəd bi daʊnɹaɪt tʃæɹəɾəbəl ə ju. pipəl laɪk ə tʃæɹəɾəbəl fɛloʊ."

"Order another round," she said immediately. "For the entire bar. It would be downright charitable of you. People like a charitable fellow."

"aɪ mɛn əbaʊt ðə lɛɾɝ."

"I meant about the letter."

"ju pɹɑməs nɑt tə oʊpən ɪt?" ʃi sɛd.

"You promised not to open it?" she said.

"wɛl, nɑɾ ɪɡzækli. aɪ pɹɑməs ðəɾ ɪf aɪ oʊpən ɪt, aɪd də ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ɪt sɛɾ ɪnsaɪd."

"Well, not exactly. I promised that if I opened it, I'd do exactly what it said inside."

"ɡeɪv ən oʊθ, dɪd ju?"

"Gave an oath, did you?"

hi nɑɾəd.

He nodded.

ʃi snætʃt ɪt fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, kɑzɪŋ ɪm tə jɛlp. hi ɹitʃt tə teɪk ɪt bæk bʌt ʃi pʊld əweɪ, tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. mæt səpɹɛst ən ɝdʒ tə ɹitʃ fəɹ ɪɾ əɡɛn; hi hæd pleɪd mɔɹ ðən ə fju ɡeɪmz ə teɪk-əweɪ, ən hæd noʊ ɝdʒ tə lʊk ðə bəfun. ə wʊmən laɪk nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tə meɪk ə mæn skwɝm, ən ɪf jə lɛɾ əɹ də ɪt, ʃi wəɾ oʊnli kip ɡoʊɪŋ.

She snatched it from his fingers, causing him to yelp. He reached to take it back but she pulled away, turning it over in her fingers. Mat suppressed an urge to reach for it again; he had played more than a few games of take-away, and had no urge to look the buffoon. A woman liked nothing more than to make a man squirm, and if you let her do it, she would only keep going.

stɪl, hi bɪɡæn tə swɛt. "naʊ, mɛli . . ."

Still, he began to sweat. "Now, Melli . . ."

"aɪ kəɾ oʊpən ɪt fəɹ ju," ʃi sɛd, linɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə bɑɹ, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə lɛɾɝ. nɪɹbaɪ, ə mæn kɔl fəɹ ənʌðɝ mʌɡ ʌv eɪl, bʌt ʃi weɪvd ɪm daʊn. ðə ɹɛd-noʊz mæn lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd hæɾ ɪnʌf ɛniweɪ. mɛliz tævɝn wɑz pɑpjəlɝ ɪnʌf ðət ʃi hæɾ ə hæf-dʌzən sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ə ðə peɪtʃɹənz. wʌn wəd ɡɛt tə hɪm ɪvɛntʃəwəli. "aɪ kəɾ oʊpən ɪt," ʃi kəntɪnjud tə mæt, "æn kəd tɛl jə wʌts ɪnsaɪd."

"I could open it for you," she said, leaning back against the other side of the bar, looking over the letter. Nearby, a man called for another mug of ale, but she waved him down. The red-nosed man looked as if he had had enough anyway. Melli's tavern was popular enough that she had a half-dozen serving girls taking care of the patrons. One would get to him eventually. "I could open it," she continued to Mat, "and could tell you what's inside."

blʌɾi æʃəz! ɪf ʃi dɪd ðæt, hi wəɾ əv tə də wʌɾ ɪt sɛd. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt blʌɾi sɛd! ɔl i hæd tə də wɑz weɪɾ ə fju wiks, ən i wəd bi fɹi. hi kəd weɪt ðət lɔŋ. ɹɪli, hi kʊd. "ɪt wʊdn du," mæt sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp wɪð ə dʒɝk əz ʃi ɹitʃt əɹ θʌm bɪtwin tu saɪdz ə ðə lɛɾɝ, əz ɪf tə ɹɪp ɪt. "aɪd stɪl əv tə də wʌɾ ɪt sɛd, mɛli. doʊn jə də ðæt, naʊ. bi kɛɹfəl!"

Bloody ashes! If she did that, he would have to do what it said. Whatever it bloody said! All he had to do was wait a few weeks, and he would be free. He could wait that long. Really, he could. "It wouldn't do," Mat said, sitting up with a jerk as she reached her thumb between two sides of the letter, as if to rip it. "I'd still have to do what it said, Melli. Don't you do that, now. Be careful!"

ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm. hɝ tævɝn, ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp læs, wɑz wʌn ə ðə bɛst ɪn wɛstɝn keɪɛmlɪn.

She smiled at him. Her tavern, The Seven-Striped Lass, was one of the best in western Caemlyn.

eɪl wɪð ə ɹoʊbʌs fleɪvɝ, ɡeɪmz ə daɪs wən jə wɑntəd ðɛm, ən nɑɾ ə ɹæt tə bi sin. ðeɪ pɹɑbli dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪsk ɹʌnɪŋ əfaʊl ə mɛli.

Ale with a robust flavor, games of dice when you wanted them, and not a rat to be seen. They probably did not want to risk running afoul of Melli.

laɪt, bʌt ðə wʊmən kəd ʃeɪm ðə wɪskɝz ɔf ə mænz tʃiks wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ tʃɹaɪɪŋ. "ju nɛvɝ dɪd tɛl mi hu ɪt wɑz fɹʌm," mɛli sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ oʊvɝ. "ʃiz ə lʌvɝ, ɪzənt ʃi? ɡɑt jə taɪɾ ʌp ɪn əɹ stʃɹɪŋz?"

Light, but the woman could shame the whiskers off a man's cheeks without much trying. "You never did tell me who it was from," Melli said, turning the letter over. "She's a lover, isn't she? Got you tied up in her strings?"

ʃi hæd ðə sɛkən pɑɹt ɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf, bʌɾ ə lʌvɝ? vɛɹɪn? ɪt wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs ɪnʌf tə meɪk mæt læf. kɪsɪŋ vɛɹɪn wʊɾə bɪn əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ fʌn əz kɪsɪŋ ə laɪən. ʌv ðə tu, hi wʊɾə tʃoʊzən ðə laɪən. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn mʌtʃ lɛs laɪkli tə tʃɹaɪ tə baɪt hɪm.

She had the second part right enough, but a lover? Verin? It was ridiculous enough to make Mat laugh. Kissing Verin would have been about as much fun as kissing a lion. Of the two, he would have chosen the lion. It would have been much less likely to try to bite him.

"aɪ ɡeɪv maɪ oʊθ, mɛli," mæt sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə ʃoʊ hɪz nɝvəsnəs. "doʊn jə ɡoʊ oʊpənɪŋ ðæt, naʊ."

"I gave my oath, Melli," Mat said, trying not to show his nervousness. "Don't you go opening that, now."

"aɪ dɪdnt ɡɪv ɛni oʊθ," ʃi sɛd. "meɪbi əl ɹɛɾ ɪt, ən ðən nɑt tɛl jə wʌɾ ɪt sɛz. dʒʌst ɡɪv jə hɪns, naʊ ən ðɛn, əz ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt."

"I didn't give any oath," she said. "Maybe I'll read it, and then not tell you what it says. Just give you hints, now and then, as encouragement."

ʃi aɪd hɪm, fʊl lɪps smaɪlɪŋ. jɛs, ʃi wɑz ə pɹɪɾi wʌn. nɑɾ əz pɹɪɾi əz tuɑn, ðoʊ, wɪð əɹ bjuɾəfəl skɪn ən lɑɹdʒ aɪz. bʌt mɛli wɑz stɪl pɹɪɾi, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðoʊz lɪps ə hɝz. biɪŋ mɛɹid mɛn i kəd nɑt stɛɹ ət ðoʊz lɪps, bʌɾ i dɪd ɡɪv əɹ ɪz bɛst smaɪl. ɪt wɑz kɔl fɔɹ, ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ ɪt kəd bɹeɪk əɹ hɑɹt. hi kəd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ oʊpən ðət lɛɾɝ.

She eyed him, full lips smiling. Yes, she was a pretty one. Not as pretty as Tuon, though, with her beautiful skin and large eyes. But Melli was still pretty, particularly those lips of hers. Being married meant he could not stare at those lips, but he did give her his best smile. It was called for, this time, though it could break her heart. He could not let her open that letter.

"ɪts ðə seɪm θɪŋ, mɛli," mæt sɛd wɪnɪŋli. "ɪf jə oʊpən ðət lɛɾɝ ən aɪ doʊn də wʌɾ ɪt sɛz, maɪ oʊθ ɪz əz ɡʊɾ əz dɪʃwɔɾɝ." hi saɪd, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz wʌn weɪ tə ɡɛt ðə lɛɾɝ bæk. "ðə wʊmən u ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɛli. jə doʊnt wɑnə æŋɡɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, də ju?"

"It's the same thing, Melli," Mat said winningly. "If you open that letter and I don't do what it says, my oath is as good as dishwater." He sighed, realizing there was one way to get the letter back. "The woman who gave it to me was Aes Sedai, Melli. You don't want to anger an Aes Sedai, do you?"

"ɛɛs sədaɪ?" mɛli sʌɾənli lʊkt iɡɝ. "aɪv ɔlweɪz fænsid ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, tə si ɪf ðəl lemi dʒɔɪn ðɛm." ʃi lʊkt ət ðə lɛɾɝ, əz ɪf mɔɹ kjʊɹiəs əbaʊɾ ɪts kɑntɛns.

"Aes Sedai?" Melli suddenly looked eager. "I've always fancied going up to Tar Valon, to see if they'll let me join them." She looked at the letter, as if more curious about its contents.

laɪt! ðə wʊmən wɑz dæft. mæt hæd teɪkən əɹ fəɹ ðə sɛnsəbəl taɪp. hi ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ.

Light! The woman was daft. Mat had taken her for the sensible type. He should have known better.

hi bɪɡæn tə swɛt mɔɹ. kəɾ i ɹitʃ ðə lɛɾɝ? ʃi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɪt kloʊs. . . .

He began to sweat more. Could he reach the letter? She was holding it close. . . .

ʃi sɛɾ ɪt daʊn ɑn ðə bɑɹ bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ʃi lɛft wʌn fɪŋɡɝ ɑn ðə lɛɾɝ, dɝɛkli ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə wæks sil. "jul ɪntʃɹədus mi tə ðɪs ɛɛs sədaɪ, wən jə nɛks mit hɝ."

She set it down on the bar before him. She left one finger on the letter, directly in the middle of the wax seal. "You'll introduce me to this Aes Sedai, when you next meet her."

"ɪf aɪ si hɝ waɪl aɪm ɪn keɪɛmlɪn," mæt sɛd. "aɪ pɹɑməs ɪt."

"If I see her while I'm in Caemlyn," Mat said. "I promise it."

"kæn aɪ tʃɹʌs jə tə kip jəɹ wɝd?"

"Can I trust you to keep your word?"

hi ɡeɪv əɹ ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd lʊk. "wʌt wɑz ðɪs hoʊl blʌɾi kɑnvɝseɪʃən əbaʊt, mɛli?"

He gave her an exasperated look. "What was this whole bloody conversation about, Melli?"

ʃi læft, tɝnɪŋ ən livɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ ɑn ðə bɑɹ, gɑnə hɛlp ðə ɡæp-tuθ mæn u wɑz stɪl kɔlɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ eɪl. mæt snætʃt ðə lɛɾɝ, tʌkɪŋ ɪt kɛɹfəli ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət. blʌɾi wʊmən. ði oʊnli weɪ fəɹ ɪm tə steɪ fɹi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ plɑts wɑz tə nɛvɝ oʊpən ðɪs lɛɾɝ. wɛl, nɑɾ ɪɡzækli fɹi. mæt hæd plɛnti ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ plɑɾɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm;

She laughed, turning and leaving the letter on the bar, going to help the gap-toothed man who was still calling for more ale. Mat snatched the letter, tucking it carefully into his coat pocket. Bloody woman. The only way for him to stay free of Aes Sedai plots was to never open this letter. Well, not exactly free. Mat had plenty of Aes Sedai plotting around him;

hi hæɾ əm kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz ɪɹz. bʌɾ oʊnli ə mæn wɪð sɔdʌs fəɹ bɹeɪnz wəɾ æsk fəɹ ənʌðɝ.

he had them coming out of his ears. But only a man with sawdust for brains would ask for another.

mæt saɪd, tɝnɪŋ ɑn ɪz stul. ə vɛɹid kɹaʊd klɔɡd ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp læs. keɪɛmlɪn wɑz fʊlɝ ðən ə laɪənfɪʃ əɾ ə ʃɪpɹɪk ðiz deɪz pɹæktəkli bɝstɪŋ ət ðə simz. ðət kɛp ðə tævɝnz bɪzi. ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ səm fɑɹmɝz ɪn wɝkoʊts fɹeɪɪŋ ət ðə kɑlɝz pleɪɾ ət daɪs. mæt hæd pleɪɾ ə fju ɹaʊnz wɪð əm ɝliɝ, ən hæd peɪd fəɹ ɪz dʒɹɪŋk wɪð ðɛɹ kɔɪnz, bʌɾ i heɪɾəd ɡæmbəlɪŋ fəɹ kɑpɝz.

Mat sighed, turning on his stool. A varied crowd clogged The Seven-Striped Lass. Caemlyn was fuller than a lionfish at a shipwreck these days practically bursting at the seams. That kept the taverns busy. In the corner some farmers in workcoats fraying at the collars played at dice. Mat had played a few rounds with them earlier, and had paid for his drink with their coins, but he hated gambling for coppers.

ðə blʌf-feɪs mæn ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ wɑz stɪl dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ - mʌs bi fɔɹtin mʌɡz sɪɾɪŋ ɛmpti bɪsaɪɾ ɪm naʊ - hɪz kəmpænjənz tʃɪɹɪŋ ɪm ɔnwɝd. ə ɡɹup ə noʊbəlz sæɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə ɹɛst, ən i wʊɾə æskt əm fəɹ ə naɪs ɡeɪm ə daɪs, bʌt ði ɪkspɹɛʃənz ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz cʊɾə fɹaɪɾənd əweɪ bɛɹz. ðeɪ hæd pɹɑbli bɪn ɑn ðə ɹɔŋ saɪɾ ə ðə səksɛʃən wɔɹ.

The bluff-faced man in the corner was still drinking - must be fourteen mugs sitting empty beside him now - his companions cheering him onward. A group of nobles sat off from the rest, and he would have asked them for a nice game of dice, but the expressions on their faces could have frightened away bears. They had probably been on the wrong side of the Succession war.

mæt wɔɹ ə blæk koʊt wɪð leɪs ət ðə kʌfs. oʊnli ə lɪɾəl leɪs, ən noʊ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ɹɪlʌktənli, hi hæd lɛft ɪz waɪd-bɹɪm hæt bæk ɪn kæmp, ən i hæd ɡɹoʊn ə fju deɪz' skɹʌb ɑn ɪz tʃɪn. ðəɾ ɪtʃt laɪk i hæd fliz, ən i lʊkt ə blʌɾi ful. bʌt ðə skɹʌb meɪɾ ɪm hɑɹɾɝ tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz.

Mat wore a black coat with lace at the cuffs. Only a little lace, and no embroidery. Reluctantly, he had left his wide-brimmed hat back in camp, and he had grown a few days' scrub on his chin. That itched like he had fleas, and he looked a bloody fool. But the scrub made him harder to recognize.

wɪð ɛvɹi fʊtpæɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi hævɪŋ ə pɪktʃɝ ə hɪm, ɪt wɑz bɛs tə bi seɪf. hi wɪʃt biɪŋ tɑvɝən wəd hɛlp ɪm fəɹ wʌns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛs nɑt tə kaʊn ɑn ðæt. biɪŋ tɑvɝən hæd nɑt bɪn ɡʊd fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ i kəd tɛl.

With every footpad in the city having a picture of him, it was best to be safe. He wished being ta'veren would help him for once, but it was best not to count on that. Being ta'veren had not been good for anything he could tell.

hi kɛpt ɪz skɑɹf tʌk loʊ ən ɪz koʊt bʌɾənd, ðə haɪ kɑlɝ ʌp nɪɹli tə hɪz tʃɪn. hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi daɪd wʌns, hi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən, ən wɑz nɑɾ iɡɝ tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn.

He kept his scarf tucked low and his coat buttoned, the high collar up nearly to his chin. He had already died once, he was fairly certain, and was not eager to try again.

ə pɹɪɾi sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl wɔk baɪ, slɛndɝ ən waɪd-hɪpt, wɪð lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ ʃi lɛt hæŋ fɹi.

A pretty serving girl walked by, slender and wide-hipped, with long dark hair she let hang free.

hi muv tə ðə saɪd, əlaʊɪŋ ɪz ɛmpti mʌɡ tə lʊk loʊnli ən ɑbviəs ɑn ðə kaʊntɝ, ən ʃi wɔkt oʊvɝ wɪð ə smaɪl tə ɹifɪl ɪt. hi ɡɹɪn əɾ əɹ ən tɪpt ə kɑpɝ. hi wɑz ə mɛɹid mæn, ən kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə tʃɑɹm hɝ, bʌɾ i kəd kip ən aɪ aʊt fəɹ ɪz fɹɛnz. θɔɹn maɪt laɪk hɝ.

He moved to the side, allowing his empty mug to look lonely and obvious on the counter, and she walked over with a smile to refill it. He grinned at her and tipped a copper. He was a married man, and could not afford to charm her, but he could keep an eye out for his friends. Thorn might like her.

ə ɡɝl maɪt meɪk ɪm stɑp moʊpɪŋ əbaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ, ət list. mæt wɑtʃt ðə ɡɝlz feɪs fəɹ ə taɪm tə bi sɝɾən i wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ əɡɛn.

A girl might make him stop moping about so much, at least. Mat watched the girl's face for a time to be certain he would recognize her again.

mæt sɪpt əɾ ɪz eɪl, wʌn hæn filɪŋ ət ðə lɛɾɝ ɪn ɪz pɑkət. hi dɪd nɑt spɛkjəleɪɾ ət wʌt wɑz ɪn ɪt. də ðæt, ən i wəd bi oʊnli wʌn stɛp fɹəm ɹɪpɪŋ ɪɾ oʊpən. hi wɑz ə lɪɾəl laɪk ə maʊs stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə tʃɹæp wɪð moʊldi tʃiz ɪn ɪt. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn ðət tʃiz. ɪt kəd ɹɑt, fəɹ ɔl i kɛɹd.

Mat sipped at his ale, one hand feeling at the letter in his pocket. He did not speculate at what was in it. Do that, and he would be only one step from ripping it open. He was a little like a mouse staring at a trap with moldy cheese in it. He did not want that cheese. It could rot, for all he cared.

ðə lɛɾɝ wəd pɹɑbli ɪnstʃɹʌkt ɪm tə də sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs. ən ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ. ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ ə fɑndnəs fəɹ meɪkɪŋ mɛn lʊk laɪk fulz. laɪɾ i hoʊp ðət ʃi hæd nɑt lɛft ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fəɹ ɪm tə hɛlp sʌmwʌn ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. ɪf ðət wɝ ðə keɪs, ʃʊɹli ʃi wʊɾə sin tə ɪt hɝsɛlf.

The letter would probably instruct him to do something dangerous. And embarrassing. Aes Sedai had a fondness for making men look like fools. Light he hoped that she had not left instructions for him to help someone in trouble. If that were the case, surely she would have seen to it herself.

hi saɪɾ ən tʊk ənʌðɝ pʊl ɑn ɪz eɪl. ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ðə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ mæn faɪnəli tɑpəld oʊvɝ. sɪkstin mʌɡz. nɑt bæd. mæt sɛɾ əsaɪɾ ɪz oʊn dʒɹɪŋk, lɛft ə fju kɔɪnz əz peɪmənt, ðən nɑɾəd fɛɹwɛl tə mɛli. hi kəlɛktəɾ ɪz wɪnɪŋz ɑn ðə weɪdʒɝ ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ mæn fɹəm ə lɔŋ-fɪŋɡɝd fɛloʊ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. mæt hæd bɛɾ ɑn sɛvəntin mʌɡz, wɪtʃ wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə wɪn sʌm. ðən i wɑz ɑn ɪz weɪ, teɪkɪŋ ɪz wɔkɪŋ stɪk fɹəm ðə stæn baɪ ðə dɔɹ.

He sighed and took another pull on his ale. In the corner, the drinking man finally toppled over. Sixteen mugs. Not bad. Mat set aside his own drink, left a few coins as payment, then nodded farewell to Melli. He collected his winnings on the wager regarding the drinking man from a long-fingered fellow in the corner. Mat had bet on seventeen mugs, which was close enough to win some. Then he was on his way, taking his walking stick from the stand by the door.

ðə baʊnsɝ, bɝɡ, aɪd hɪm. bɝɡ hæɾ ə feɪs ʌɡli ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪz oʊn mʌðɝ wɪns. ðə ʃoʊldɝθʌmpɝ dɪd nɑt laɪk mæt, ən fɹəm ðə weɪ bɝɡ lʊkt ət mɛli, ðət wɑz pɹɑbli kəz i fɪɡjɝd mæt wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aɪz əɾ ɪz wʊmən. nɛvɝ maɪn ðət mæt hæɾ ɪkspleɪn i wɑz mɛɹid, ən dɪd nɑt də ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. səm mɛn wəd bi dʒɛləs noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ toʊld.

The bouncer, Berg, eyed him. Berg had a face ugly enough to make his own mother wince. The shoulderthumper did not like Mat, and from the way Berg looked at Melli, that was probably because he figured Mat was trying to make eyes at his woman. Never mind that Mat had explained he was married, and did not do that sort of thing any longer. Some men would be jealous no matter what they were told.

ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn wɝ bɪzi, ivən ət ðɪs leɪɾ aʊɝ. ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz wɝ dæmp fɹəm ə ɹisənt ʃaʊɝ, ðoʊ ðoʊz klaʊdz hæd pæs baɪ ən - ɹɪmɑɹkəbli - lɛf ðə skaɪ oʊpən tə ði ɛɹ. hi muv nɔɹθwɝɾ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit, hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ tævɝn i nu, wʌn wɛɹ mɛn daɪs fəɹ sɪlvɝ ən ɡoʊld. mæt wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊɾ ɛni spəsɪfɪk tæsk tənaɪt, dʒʌs lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ ɹumɝz, ɡɛɾɪŋ ə fil fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn. ə lɑt hæd tʃeɪnʒd sɪns i hæd bɪn hɪɹ læst.

The streets of Caemlyn were busy, even at this late hour. The paving stones were damp from a recent shower, though those clouds had passed by and - remarkably - left the sky open to the air. He moved northward along the street, heading for another tavern he knew, one where men diced for silver and gold. Mat was not about any specific task tonight, just listening for rumors, getting a feel for Caemlyn. A lot had changed since he had been here last.
