əz i wɔkt, hi kəd nɑt hɛlp lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðoʊz blʌɾi pɪktʃɝz hæɾ ɪm ənnɝvd. mɛni ʌv ðə pipəl ɑn ðə stʃɹit sim səspɪʃəs. ə fju mʊɹændiənz pæst, lʊkɪŋ soʊ dʒɹʌŋk ðəɾ i cʊɾə lɪt ðɛɹ bɹɛθ ɑn faɪɝ. mæt kɛpt ɪz dɪstəns. æftɝ wʌt hæd hæpən tə hɪm ɪn hɪndɝstæp, hi fɪɡjɝɾ i kəd nɑt bi tu kɛɹfəl. laɪt, hi hæd hɝd stɔɹiz ə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ətækɪŋ pipəl. ɪf ə mæn kəd nɑt tʃɹʌs ðə ɹɑks ʌndɝ ɪz fit, wʌt kəɾ i tʃɹʌst?

As he walked, he could not help looking over his shoulder. Those bloody pictures had him unnerved. Many of the people on the street seemed suspicious. A few Murandians passed, looking so drunk that he could have lit their breath on fire. Mat kept his distance. After what had happened to him in Hinderstap, he figured he could not be too careful. Light, he had heard stories of paving stones attacking people. If a man could not trust the rocks under his feet, what could he trust?

hi ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹitʃt ðə tævɝn i wɑntəd, ə tʃɪɹi pleɪs kɔl ðə dɛd mænz bɹɛθ. ɪt hæd tu tʌfs aʊt fɹʌnt, hoʊldɪŋ kʌdʒəlz ðeɪ pæɾəd əɡɛnst ɪnɔɹməs pɑmz. lɑts ʌv ɛkstʃɹə tævɝn tʌfs wɝ biɪŋ haɪɝd ðiz deɪz. mæt wəɾ əv tə wɑtʃ hɪmsɛlf, nɑt wɪn tu mʌtʃ. tævɝn-kipɝz dɪd nɑt laɪk ə mæn wɪnɪŋ tu mʌtʃ, əz ɪt kəd bɹɪŋ ə faɪt. ənlɛs ðə mæn spɛn ɪz wɪnɪŋz ɑn fuɾ ən dʒɹɪŋk. ðən i kəd wɪn ɔl i laɪkt, θæŋk jə vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

He eventually reached the tavern he wanted, a cheery place called The Dead Man's Breath. It had two toughs out front, holding cudgels they patted against enormous palms. Lots of extra tavern toughs were being hired these days. Mat would have to watch himself, not win too much. Tavern-keepers did not like a man winning too much, as it could bring a fight. Unless the man spent his winnings on food and drink. Then he could win all he liked, thank you very much.

ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðɪs tævɝn wɑz dɑɹkɝ ðən ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp læs hæd bɪn. ðə mɛn hɪɹ hʌntʃt loʊ oʊvɝ dʒɹɪŋks əɹ ɡeɪmz, ən ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ fud biɪŋ sɝvd. dʒʌst stʃɹɔŋ dʒɹɪŋks. ðə wʊɾən bɑɹ hæd neɪlz huz hɛdz dʒʌɾɪd aʊɾ ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl əɹ soʊ haɪ ən dʒæb jə ɪn ði ɑɹmz. mæt fɪɡjɝd ðeɪ wɝ wɝkɪŋ tə pʊl ðɛmsɛlvz fɹi ən ɹʌn fəɹ ðə dɔɹ.

The inside of this tavern was darker than The Seven-Striped Lass had been. The men here hunched low over drinks or games, and there was not much food being served. Just strong drinks. The wooden bar had nails whose heads jutted out a fingernail or so high and jabbed you in the arms. Mat figured they were working to pull themselves free and run for the door.

ðə tɑvɝŋkipɝ, bɝnhɝd, wɑz ə ɡɹisi-hɛɹd tɛɹən wɪð ə maʊθ soʊ smɔl ɪt lʊk laɪk i hæd swɑloʊɾ ɪz lɪps baɪ mɪsteɪk. hi smɛld ə ɹæɾɪʃɪz, ən mæt hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪm smaɪl, nɑɾ ivən wən tɪpt. moʊs tɑvɝŋkipɝz wəd smaɪl ət ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ə tɪp.

The tavernkeeper, Bernherd, was a greasy-haired Tairen with a mouth so small it looked like he had swallowed his lips by mistake. He smelled of radishes, and Mat had never seen him smile, not even when tipped. Most tavernkeepers would smile at the Dark One himself for a tip.

mæt heɪɾəd ɡæmbəlɪŋ ən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪn ə pleɪs wɛɹ jə hæd tə kip wʌn hæn ɑn jəɹ kɔɪn pɝs.

Mat hated gambling and drinking in a place where you had to keep one hand on your coin purse.

bʌɾ i hæɾ ə maɪn tə wɪn səm ɹil mʌni tənaɪt, ən ðəɹ wɝ daɪs ɡeɪmz ɡoʊɪŋ ən kɔɪnz klɪŋkɪŋ, soʊ hi fɛl sʌmwʌɾ ət hoʊm. ðə leɪs ɑn ɪz koʊt dɪd ɡɛt ɡlænsɪz. waɪ hæɾ i teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ ðæt, ɛniweɪ? bɛst əv ləpɪn pʊl ɪɾ ɔf ɪz kʌfs wən i ɡɑt bæk tə ðə kæmp. wɛl, nɑɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt. səm ʌv ɪt, meɪbi.

But he had a mind to win some real money tonight, and there were dice games going and coins clinking, so he felt somewhat at home. The lace on his coat did get glances. Why had he taken to wearing that, anyway? Best have Lopin pull it off his cuffs when he got back to the camp. Well, not all of it. Some of it, maybe.

mæt faʊn ə ɡeɪm ət ðə bæk biɪŋ pleɪd baɪ θɹi mɛn ən ə wʊmən ɪn bɹitʃɪz. ʃi hæd ʃɔɹt ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ən naɪs aɪz; mæt noʊɾəst ðoʊz pjʊɹli fəɹ θɔɹnz seɪk. ʃi hæɾ ə fʊl bʊzəm, ɛniweɪ, ən leɪtli mæt hæɾ ə maɪn fəɹ wɪmən u wɝ mɔɹ slɛndɝ θɹu ðə tʃɛst.

Mat found a game at the back being played by three men and a woman in breeches. She had short golden hair and nice eyes; Mat noticed those purely for Thorn's sake. She had a full bosom, anyway, and lately Mat had a mind for women who were more slender through the chest.

ɪn mɪnəts mæt wɑz dɪsɪŋ wɪð ðɛm, ən ðət kɑmd ɪm ə mɛʒɝ. hi kɛpt ɪz kɔɪn paʊtʃ ɪn saɪt, ðoʊ, leɪɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ðə paɪl ə kɔɪnz bɪsaɪɾ ɪt ɡɹu, moʊsli sɪlvɝz.

In minutes Mat was dicing with them, and that calmed him a measure. He kept his coin pouch in sight, though, laying it on the floor in front of him. Before long, the pile of coins beside it grew, mostly silvers.

"ju hɪɹ əbaʊt wʌt hæpən oʊvɝ ət fɛɹiɝz ɡɹin?" wʌn ə ðə mɛn æskt ɪz fɛloʊz əz mæt tɔst. "ɪt wɑz ə tɛɹəbəl θɪŋ." ðə spikɝ wɑz ə tɔl fɛloʊ, wɪð ə pɪntʃt-ʌp feɪs ðət lʊk laɪk ɪt hæd bɪn kloʊzd ɪn ə dɔɹ ə fju taɪmz. hi kɔl hɪmsɛlf tʃeɪsɝ. mæt fɪɡjɝd ðət wɑz kəz ðə wɪmən ɹæn əweɪ fɹəm ɪm æftɝ ðeɪ ɡɑɾ ə lʊk ət ðət feɪs, ən i hæd tə ɹʌn æftɝ ðɛm.

"You hear about what happened over at Farrier's Green?" one of the men asked his fellows as Mat tossed. "It was a terrible thing." The speaker was a tall fellow, with a pinched-up face that looked like it had been closed in a door a few times. He called himself Chaser. Mat figured that was because the women ran away from him after they got a look at that face, and he had to run after them.

"wʌt?" klɛɹ æskt. ʃi wɑz ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən. mæt ɡeɪv əɹ ə smaɪl. hi dɪd nɑt daɪs əɡɛnst wɪmən mʌtʃ, əz moʊs kleɪm tə faɪn dɪsɪŋ ɪmpɹɑpɝ. nɛvɝ maɪn ðət ðeɪ nɛvɝ kəmpleɪnd wən ə mæn bɑɾ əm sʌmθɪŋ naɪs wɪð wʌɾ i hæd wʌn. ɛniweɪ, dɪsɪŋ wɪð wɪmən wɑz nɑt fɛɹ, sɪns wʌn ə hɪz smaɪlz kəd sɛt ðɛɹ hɑɹts flʌɾɝɪŋ ən ðeɪ wəd ɡɛɾ ɔl wik ɪn ðə niz. bʌt mæt dɪd nɑt smaɪl ət ɡɝlz ðət weɪ ɛnimɔɹ. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪspɑndɪd tə ɛni ʌv ɪz smaɪlz ɛniweɪ.

"What?" Clare asked. She was the golden-haired woman. Mat gave her a smile. He did not dice against women much, as most claimed to find dicing improper. Never mind that they never complained when a man bought them something nice with what he had won. Anyway, dicing with women was not fair, since one of his smiles could set their hearts fluttering and they would get all weak in the knees. But Mat did not smile at girls that way anymore. Besides, she had not responded to any of his smiles anyway.

"dʒoʊɾɝi," tʃeɪsɝ sɛɾ əz mæt ʃʊk ɪz daɪs. "ðeɪ faʊn ɪm dɛd ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. θɹoʊt ɹɪp klin aʊt. bɑɾi wɑz dʒɹeɪn ə blʌd, laɪk ə waɪnɛskɪn fʊl ə hoʊlz."

"Jowdry," Chaser said as Mat shook his dice. "They found him dead this morning. Throat ripped clean out. Body was drained of blood, like a wineskin full of holes."

mæt wɑz soʊ stɑɹɾəld ðəɾ i θɹu ðə daɪs, bʌt dɪd nɑt wɑtʃ əm ɹoʊl. "wʌt?" hi dɪmændəd.

Mat was so startled that he threw the dice, but did not watch them roll. "What?" he demanded.

"wʌt dɪd jə seɪ?"

"What did you say?"

"hɪɹ naʊ," tʃeɪsɝ sɛd, lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd mæt. "ɪts dʒʌst sʌmwʌn wi nu. oʊd mi tu kɹaʊnz, hi dɪd."

"Here now," Chaser said, looking toward Mat. "It's just someone we knew. Owed me two crowns, he did."

"dʒɹeɪn ə blʌd," mæt sɛd, "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ? dɪd jə si ðə bɑɾi?" "wʌt?" tʃeɪsɝ sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "blʌɾi æʃəz, mæn! wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð ju?"

"Drained of blood," Mat said, "Are you sure? Did you see the body?" "What?" Chaser said, grimacing. "Bloody ashes, man! What's wrong with you?"

"tʃeɪsɝ," klɛɹ sɛd. "wɪl jə lʊk ət ðæt?"

"Chaser," Clare said. "Will you look at that?"

ðə lin mæn ɡlæns daʊn, əz dɪd mæt. ðə daɪs i hæd tɔst - ɔl θɹi ʌv əm - hæd lændəd stɪl ən wɝ bælənst ɑn ðɛɹ kɔɹnɝz. laɪt! hi hæd tɔs kɔɪnz soʊ ðeɪ fɛl ɑn ðɛɹ saɪdz bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ dʌn ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs.

The lean man glanced down, as did Mat. The dice he had tossed - all three of them - had landed still and were balanced on their corners. Light! He had tossed coins so they fell on their sides before, but he had never done anything like this.

ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən, ðə daɪs stɑɹɾəd ɹætlɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. hi ɔlmoʊs dʒʌmp klɪɹ tə ðə silɪŋ. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! ðoʊz daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd nɛvɝ mɛn ɛniθɪŋ ɡʊd. ðeɪ oʊnli stɑpt wən sʌmθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd, sʌmθɪŋ ðət juʒəwəli mɛn bæd nuz fəɹ pʊɹ meɪtʃɹim kɔθən.

Right there, all of a sudden, the dice started rattling inside his head. He almost jumped clear to the ceiling. Blood and bloody ashes! Those dice in his head never meant anything good. They only stopped when something changed, something that usually meant bad news for poor Matrim Cauthon.

"aɪ eɪnt nɛvɝ . . ." tʃeɪsɝ sɛd.

"I ain't never . . ." Chaser said.

"wil kɔl ðəɾ ə lɔs," mæt sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ə fju kɔɪnz daʊn ən skupɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz wɪnɪŋz.

"We'll call that a loss," Mat said, tossing a few coins down and scooping up the rest of his winnings.

"wʌt dʒju noʊ əbaʊt dʒoʊɾɝi?" klɛɹ dɪmændəd. ʃi wɑz ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ weɪst. mæt wʊɾə bɛt ɡoʊld əɡɛns kɑpɝz ɑn əɹ hævɪŋ ə naɪf ðɛɹ, ðə weɪ ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm.

"What do you know about Jowdry?" Clare demanded. She was reaching for her waist. Mat would have bet gold against coppers on her having a knife there, the way she glared at him.

"nʌθɪŋ," mæt sɛd. nʌθɪŋ ən tu mʌtʃ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "ɪkskjus mi."

"Nothing," Mat said. Nothing and too much at the same time. "Excuse me."

hi heɪstəli kɹɔs ðə tævɝn. əz i dɪd, hi noʊɾəst wʌn ə ðə θɪk-ɑɹm tʌfs fɹəm ðə dɔɹ stændɪŋ ən tɔkɪŋ tə bɝnhɝd ðə tævɝn-kipɝ, pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ə pis ə peɪpɝ ɪn ɪz hænz. mæt kəd nɑt si wʌt wɑz ɑn ɪt, bʌɾ i kəd ɡɛs: hɪz oʊn feɪs.

He hastily crossed the tavern. As he did, he noticed one of the thick-armed toughs from the door standing and talking to Bernherd the tavern-keeper, pointing at a piece of paper in his hands. Mat could not see what was on it, but he could guess: his own face.

hi kɝst ən dʌkt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹit. hi tʊk ðə fɝst æli hi sɔ, bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə ə ɹʌn.

He cursed and ducked out onto the street. He took the first alley he saw, breaking into a run.

ðə fɔɹseɪkən hʌntɪŋ hɪm, ə pɪktʃɝ ə hɪz feɪs ɪn ðə pɑkəɾ ʌv ɛvɹi fʊtpæɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ən ə kɔɹps kɪld ən dʒɹeɪn ʌv ɪts blʌd. ðət kəɾ oʊnli min wʌn θɪŋ. ðə ɡoʊləm wɑz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn.

The Forsaken hunting him, a picture of his face in the pocket of every footpad in the city and a corpse killed and drained of its blood. That could only mean one thing. The gholam was in Caemlyn.

ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðəɾ ɪt cʊɾə ɡɑɾən hɪɹ ðɪs kwɪkli. ʌv kɔɹs, mæt hæd sin ɪt skwiz θɹu ə hoʊl nɑt tu hændspænz waɪd. ðə θɪŋ dɪd nɑt sim tə hæv ə ɹaɪt sɛns ʌv wʌt wɑz pɑsəbəl ən wʌt wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl.

It seemed impossible that it could have gotten here this quickly. Of course, Mat had seen it squeeze through a hole not two handspans wide. The thing did not seem to have a right sense of what was possible and what was not possible.

blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, hi θɔt, dʌkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. hi niɾəd tə kəlɛk θɔɹn ən ɡɛt bæk tə ðə bænz kæmp aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. hi heɪsən daʊn ðə dɑɹk, ɹeɪn-slɪk stʃɹit. peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ɹəflɛktəd ðə lɪɾ ɔɪl læmps əhɛd. ɪleɪn kɛp ðə kwinz wɔk wɛl ɪluməneɪɾəd ət naɪt.

Blood and bloody ashes, he thought, ducking his head. He needed to collect Thorn and get back to the Band's camp outside of the city. He hastened down the dark, rain-slicked street. Paving stones reflected the lit oil lamps ahead. Elayne kept the Queen's Walk well illuminated at night.

hi hæd sɛnt wɝd tə hɝ, bʌt hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən ə ɹɪplaɪ. haʊ wɑz ðət fəɹ ɡɹæɾətud? baɪ hɪz kaʊnt, hi hæd seɪvd əɹ laɪf twaɪs. wʌns ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf tə ɹədus əɹ tə tɛɹz ən kɪsəz, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt sin ivən ə pɛk ɑn ðə tʃik. nɑt ðəɾ i wɑntəd wʌn; nɑt fɹəm ɹɔɪəlti. bɛs tə əvɔɪd ! ðɛm.

He had sent word to her, but had not gotten a reply. How was that for gratitude? By his count, he had saved her life twice. Once should have been enough to reduce her to tears and kisses, but he had not seen even a peck on the cheek. Not that he wanted one; not from royalty. Best to avoid ! them.

jəɹ mɛɹid tə ə blʌɾi haɪ leɪɾi ʌv ðə simən, hi θɔt. dɔɾɝ ə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf ðəɹ wɑz noʊ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɹɔɪəlti naʊ! nɑt fəɹ hɪm. ət lis tuɑn wɑz pɹɪɾi. ən ɡʊɾ ət pleɪɪŋ stoʊnz. ən vɛɹi kin ʌv wɪt, ɡʊd fəɹ tɔkɪŋ tə, ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz fleɪmɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ moʊst ə ðə . . .

You're married to a bloody high lady of the Seamhan, he thought. Daughter of the Empress herself There was no avoiding royalty now! Not for him. At least Tuon was pretty. And good at playing stones. And very keen of wit, good for talking to, even if she was flaming frustrating most of the . . .

noʊ. noʊ θɪŋkɪŋ ə tuɑn ɹaɪt naʊ.

No. No thinking of Tuon right now.

ɛniweɪ, hi hæd ɹəsiv noʊ ɹɪplaɪ fɹəm ɪleɪn. hi wəd nid tə bi mɔɹ fɝm. ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌst ɑlʌdʒɹə ən əɹ dʒɹæɡənz naʊ. ðə blʌɾi ɡoʊləm wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi.

Anyway, he had received no reply from Elayne. He would need to be more firm. It was not just Aludra and her dragons now. The bloody gholam was in the city.

hi stɛpt aʊɾ ɑntu ə lɑɹdʒ, bɪzi stʃɹit, hænz pʊʃt ɪndə ðə pɑkəts ə hɪz koʊt. ɪn ɪz heɪst, hi hæd lɛft ɪz wɔkɪŋ stæf bæk ɪn ðə dɛd mænz bɹɛθ. hi ɡɹʌmbəl tə hɪmsɛlf; hi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi spɛndɪŋ ɪz deɪz ɹɪlæksɪŋ, hɪz naɪts dɪsɪŋ ɪn faɪn ɪnz, ən ɪz mɔɹnɪŋz slipɪŋ leɪt waɪl weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ vɛɹɪnz θɝɾi-deɪ ɹɪkwaɪɹmən tə ɹʌn aʊt. naʊ ðɪs.

He stepped out onto a large, busy street, hands pushed into the pockets of his coat. In his haste, he had left his walking staff back in The Dead Man's Breath. He grumbled to himself; he was supposed to be spending his days relaxing, his nights dicing in fine inns, and his mornings sleeping late while waiting for Verin's thirty-day requirement to run out. Now this.

hi hæɾ ə skɔɹ tə sɛɾəl wɪð ðət ɡoʊləm. ði ɪnəsəns ɪt hæd slɔɾɝd waɪl lɝkɪŋ ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ wɝ bæɾ ɪnʌf, ən mæt hæd nɑt fɝɡɑɾən neɪlzin ən ðə faɪv ɹɛdʒɹmz u hæd bɪn mɝɾɝd iðɝ. blʌɾi æʃəz, ɪt hæd hæɾ ɪnʌf tə ænsɝ fəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðən ɪt hæd teɪkən taɪlɪn.

He had a score to settle with that gholam. The innocents it had slaughtered while lurking around Ebou Dar were bad enough, and Mat had not forgotten Nalesean and the five Redarms who had been murdered either. Bloody ashes, it had had enough to answer for already. Then it had taken Tylin.

mæt ɹimuvd ə hæn fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, filɪŋ ət ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən, ɹɛstɪŋ - əz ɔlweɪz -  əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. hi wɑz taɪɝɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðət mɑnstɝ. ə plæn stɑɹɾəd tə fɔɹm ɪn ɪz maɪnd, əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə ɹætlɪŋ ə daɪs. hi tʃɹaɪd tə bænɪʃ ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə kwin laɪɪŋ ɪn bɑnz mæt hɪmsɛlf hæd taɪd, hɝ hɛd ɹɪp fɹi. ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn soʊ mʌtʃ blʌd. ðə ɡoʊləm lɪvd ɑn fɹɛʃ blʌd.

Mat removed a hand from his pocket, feeling at the foxhead medallion, resting - as always -  against his chest. He was tired of running from that monster. A plan started to form in his mind, accompanied by the rattling of dice. He tried to banish the image of the Queen lying in bonds Mat himself had tied, her head ripped free. There would have been so much blood. The gholam lived on fresh blood.

mæt ʃɪvɝd, ʃʌvɪŋ ɪz hæn bæk ɪndə hɪz pɑkəɾ əz i əpɹoʊtʃt ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪt. dɪspaɪt ðə dɑɹknəs, hi kəd pɪk aʊt saɪnz ə ðə bæɾəl ðət hæd bɪn fɔt hɪɹ. ən æɹoʊhɛɾ ɛmbɛɾɪd ɪndə ðə dɔɹweɪ ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ tə hɪz lɛft, ə dɑɹk pætʃ ɑn ðə wɔl ʌv ə ɡɑɹdhaʊs, steɪnɪŋ ðə wʊd bɪniθ ðə wɪndoʊ. ə mæn hæd daɪd ðɛɹ, pɝhæps waɪl faɪɹɪŋ ə kɹɔsboʊ aʊt, ən hæd slʌmp daʊn oʊvɝ ðə wɪndoʊz lɛdʒ, bliɾɪŋ ɪz laɪfblʌd daʊn ðə wʊd.

Mat shivered, shoving his hand back into his pocket as he approached the city gate. Despite the darkness, he could pick out signs of the battle that had been fought here. An arrowhead embedded into the doorway of a building to his left, a dark patch on the wall of a guardhouse, staining the wood beneath the window. A man had died there, perhaps while firing a crossbow out, and had slumped down over the windows ledge, bleeding his lifeblood down the wood.

ðət sidʒ wɑz oʊvɝ naʊ, ən ə nu kwin - ðə ɹaɪt kwin - hɛl ðə θɹoʊn. fəɹ wʌns, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə bæɾəl ən i hæd mɪst ɪt. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət laɪɾənd ɪz mud sʌmwʌt. ən ɪntaɪɝ wɔɹ hæd bɪn fɔɾ oʊvɝ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, ən nɑt wʌn æɹoʊ, bleɪɾ əɹ spɪɹ hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə kɑnflɪk sikɪŋ meɪtʃɹim kɔθənz hɑɹt.

That siege was over now, and a new Queen - the right Queen - held the throne. For once, there had been a battle and he had missed it. Remembering that lightened his mood somewhat. An entire war had been fought over the Lion Throne, and not one arrow, blade or spear had entered the conflict seeking Matrim Cauthon's heart.

hi tɝn ɹaɪt, əlɔŋ ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi wɔl. ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪnz hɪɹ. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ɪnz nɪɹ sɪɾi ɡeɪts. nɑt ðə naɪsɪst wʌnz, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ðə moʊs pɹɑfəɾəbəl wʌnz.

He turned right, along the inside of the city wall. There were a lot of inns here. There were always inns near city gates. Not the nicest ones, but almost always the most profitable ones.

laɪt spɪl fɹəm dɔɹweɪz ən wɪndoʊz, peɪntɪŋ ðə ɹoʊd ɡoʊldən ɪn ætʃəz. dɑɹk fɔɹmz kɹaʊɾəd ði æliweɪz ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ði ɪnz hæd haɪɝd mɛn tə kip ðə pʊɹ əweɪ. keɪɛmlɪn wɑz stʃɹeɪnd. ðə flʌɾ ə ɹɛfjudʒiz, ðə ɹisən faɪɾɪŋ, ði . . . ʌðɝ mæɾɝz. stɔɹiz əbaʊndəɾ ə ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ, ʌv fud spɔɪlɪŋ, ʌv waɪtwɑʃt wɔlz sʌɾənli ɡoʊɪŋ ɡɹaɪmi.

Light spilled from doorways and windows, painting the road golden in atches. Dark forms crowded the alleyways except where the inns had hired men to keep the poor away. Caemlyn was strained. The flood of refugees, the recent fighting, the . . . other matters. Stories abounded of the dead walking, of food spoiling, of whitewashed walls suddenly going grimy.

ði ɪn wɛɹ θɔɹn hæd tʃoʊzən tə pɝfɔɹm wɑz ə stip-ɹuft, bɹɪk-fɹʌntɪd stʃɹʌktʃɝ wɪð ə saɪn ðət ʃoʊd tu æpəlz, wʌn iɾən daʊn tə ðə kɔɹ. ðət meɪɾ ɪt stɑɹk waɪt, ði ʌðɝ wɑz stɑɹk ɹɛd - kʌlɝz .ʌv ði æn-dɔɹæn flæɡ. ðə tu æpəlz wɑz wʌn ə ðə naɪsɝ ɛstæblɪʃməns ɪn ði ɛɹiə.

The inn where Thorn had chosen to perform was a steep-roofed, brick-fronted structure with a sign that showed two apples, one eaten down to the core. That made it stark white, the other was stark red - colors .of the An-doran flag. The Two Apples was one of the nicer establishments in the area.

mæt kəd hɪɹ ðə mjuzɪk fɹəm aʊtsaɪd. hi ɛntɝɾ ən sɔ θɔɹn sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ə smɔl deɪz ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə kɑmən ɹum, pleɪɪŋ ɪz fluɾ ən wɛɹɪŋ ɪz pætʃwɝk ɡlimənz kloʊk. hɪz aɪz wɝ kloʊzd əz i pleɪd, hɪz mʌstæʃ dʒɹupɪŋ lɔŋ ən waɪɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɪnstʃɹəmənt. ɪt wɑz ə hɔntɪŋ tun, "ðə mɛɹɪdʒ ə sɪni weɪd." mæt hæd lɝn ɪɾ əz "ɔlweɪz tʃuz ðə ɹaɪt hɔɹs," ən stɪl wɑz nɑt juz tə ɪt biɪŋ pɝfɔɹmd əz sloʊli əz tɑm dɪd.

Mat could hear the music from outside. He entered and saw Thorn sitting atop a small dais on the far side of the common room, playing his flute and wearing his patchwork gleeman's cloak. His eyes were closed as he played, his mustache drooping long and white on either side of the instrument. It was a haunting tune, "The Marriage of Cinny Wade." Mat had learned it as "Always Choose the Right Horse," and still was not used to it being performed as slowly as Thom did.

ə smɔl kəlɛkʃən ə kɔɪnz wɑz skæɾɝd ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə tɑm. ði ɪn əlaʊɾ ɪm tə pleɪ fəɹ tɪps. mæt stɑp nɪɹ ðə dɔɹweɪ ən lin bæk tə lɪsən. noʊbɑdi spoʊk ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz stʌf soʊ fʊl mæt cʊɾə meɪd hæf ə kʌmpəni ʌv soʊlʒɝz dʒʌst wɪð ðə mɛn ɪnsaɪd. ɛvɹi aɪ wɑz ɑn tɑm.

A small collection of coins was scattered on the floor in front of Thom. The inn allowed him to play for tips. Mat stopped near the doorway and leaned back to listen. Nobody spoke in the common room, though it was stuffed so full Mat could have made half a company of soldiers just with the men inside. Every eye was on Thom.

mæt hæd bɪn ɔl ɝaʊn ðə wɝl naʊ, wɔkɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɪɾ ɑn ɪz oʊn tu fit. hi hæd nɪɹli lɔst ɪz skɪn ɪn ə dʌzən dɪfɹən sɪɾiz, ən hæd steɪɾ ɪn ɪnz fɑɹ ən nɪɹ. hi hæd hɝd ɡlimən, pɝfɔɹmɝz ən bɑɹdz. tɑm meɪd ði ɪntaɪɝ lɑt sim laɪk tʃɪlʒɹən wɪð stɪks, bæŋɪŋ ɑn pɑts.

Mat had been all around the world now, walking a great deal of it on his own two feet. He had nearly lost his skin in a dozen different cities, and had stayed in inns far and near. He had heard gleemen, performers and bards. Thom made the entire lot seem like children with sticks, banging on pots.

ðə flut wɑz ə sɪmpəl ɪnstʃɹəmənt. ə lɑɾ ə noʊbəlz wəd ɹæðɝ hɪɹ ðə hɑɹp ɪnstɛd; wʌn mæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ hæd toʊl mæt ðə hɑɹp wɑz mɔɹ ɛləveɪɾɪd." mæt fɪɡjɝɾ i wʊɾə ɡɔn slæk-dʒɔɾ ən sɔsɝ-aɪɾ ɪf i hæd hɝd tɑm pleɪ. ðə ɡlimən meɪd ðə flut saʊn laɪk ən ɪkstɛnʃən ə hɪz oʊn soʊl. sɑf tʃɹɪlz, maɪnɝ skeɪlz ən paʊɝfli boʊld lɔŋ hoʊlz. sətʃ ə ləmɛntɪŋ mɛləɾi. hu wɑz tɑm sɑɹoʊɪŋ fɔɹ?

The flute was a simple instrument. A lot of nobles would rather hear the harp instead; one man in Ebou Dar had told Mat the harp was more elevated." Mat figured he would have gone slack-jawed and saucer-eyed if he had heard Thom play. The gleeman made the flute sound like an extension of his own soul. Soft trills, minor scales and powerfully bold long holds. Such a lamenting melody. Who was Thom sorrowing for?

ðə kɹaʊd wɑtʃt. keɪɛmlɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɪɾiz ɪn ðə wɝld, bʌt stɪl ðə vɝaɪəɾi simd ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl. kɹʌsti ɪliɑnɝz sæt bɪsaɪd smuð dəmɑni, kɹæfti kɛɹhinɪn, staʊt tɛɹənz ən ə spɹɪŋklɪŋ ə bɔɹ-dɝləndɝz. keɪɛmlɪn wɑz sin əz wʌn ə ðə fju pleɪsəz wɛɹ wʌn kəd bi seɪf fɹəm boʊθ ðə sintʃæn ən ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðəɹ wɑz ə bɪɾ ə fud, tu.

The crowd watched. Caemlyn was one of the greatest cities in the world, but still the variety seemed incredible. Crusty Illianers sat beside smooth Domani, crafty Cairhienin, stout Tairens and a sprinkling of Bor-derlanders. Caemlyn was seen as one of the few places where one could be safe from both the Seanchan and the Dragon. There was a bit of food, too.

θɔɹn fɪnɪʃt ðə pis ən muvd ɑn tə ənʌðɝ wɪθaʊɾ oʊpənɪŋ hz aɪz. mæt saɪd, heɪɾɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ʌp θɔɹnz pɝfɔɹməns. ənfɔɹtʃənətli ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bi muvɪŋ ɑn bæk tə kæmp. ðeɪ hæd tə tɔk əbaʊt ði aɪ ɡoʊləm, ən mæt niɾəd tə faɪn ə weɪ tə ɡɛt θɹu tə ɪleɪn. meɪbi θɔɹn wəd ɡoʊ tɔk tə hɝ fəɹ hɪm.

Thorn finished the piece and moved on to another without opening hjs eyes. Mat sighed, hating to break up Thorn's performance. Unfortunately it was time to be moving on back to camp. They had to talk about the I gholam, and Mat needed to find a way to get through to Elayne. Maybe Thorn would go talk to her for him.

mæt nɑɾəd tə ði ɪnkipɝ - ə steɪtli, dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən neɪm bɹɑməz. ʃi nɑɾəd tə mæt, hup ɪɹɪŋz kætʃɪŋ ðə laɪt. ʃi wɑz ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən ɪz nɔɹməl teɪst - bʌt ðɛn, taɪlɪn hæd bɪn əɹ eɪdʒ. hi wəd kip əɹ ɪn maɪnd. fəɹ wʌn ə hɪz mɛn, ʌv kɔɹs. meɪbi veɪnɪn.

Mat nodded to the innkeeper - a stately, dark-haired woman named Bromas. She nodded to Mat, hoop earrings catching the light. She was a little older than his normal taste - but then, Tylin had been her age. He would keep her in mind. For one of his men, of course. Maybe Vanin.

mæt ɹitʃt ðə steɪdʒ, ðən bɪɡæn tə skup ʌp ðə kɔɪnz. hi wəd lɛt θɔɹn fɪnɪʃ ən -  mæts hæn dʒɝkt. hɪz ɑɹm wɑz sʌɾənli pɪn baɪ ðə kʌf tə ðə steɪdʒ, ə naɪf stɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə klɔθ. ðə θɪn lɛŋθ ə mɛɾəl kwɪvɝd. mæt ɡlænst ʌp tə faɪn θɔɹn stɪl pleɪɪŋ, ðoʊ ðə ɡlimən hæd kɹækt ən aɪ bɪfɔɹ θɹoʊɪŋ ðə naɪf.

Mat reached the stage, then began to scoop up the coins. He would let Thorn finish and -  Mat's hand jerked. His arm was suddenly pinned by the cuff to the stage, a knife sticking through the cloth. The thin length of metal quivered. Mat glanced up to find Thorn still playing, though the gleeman had cracked an eye before throwing the knife.

θɔɹn ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn bæk ʌp ən kəntɪnjud pleɪɪŋ, ə smaɪl ʃoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪz pʌkɝd lɪps. mæt ɡɹʌmbəld ən jæŋkt ɪz kʌf fɹi, weɪɾɪŋ əz θɔɹn fɪnɪʃt ðɪs tun, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑɾ əz doʊlfəl əz ði ʌðɝ. wən ðə læŋki ɡlimən loʊɝd ðə flut, ðə ɹum bɝst ɪndə əplɔz.

Thorn raised his hand back up and continued playing, a smile showing on his puckered lips. Mat grumbled and yanked his cuff free, waiting as Thorn finished this tune, which was not as doleful as the other. When the lanky gleeman lowered the flute, the room burst into applause.

mæt feɪvɝd ðə ɡlimən wɪð ə skaʊl. "bɝn ju, θɔɹn. ðɪs ɪz wʌn ə maɪ feɪvɹɪt koʊts!"

Mat favored the gleeman with a scowl. "Burn you, Thorn. This is one of my favorite coats!"

"bi ɡlæɾ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ eɪm fəɹ ðə hænd," θɔɹn noʊɾəd, waɪpɪŋ daʊn ðə flut, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə tʃɪɹɪŋ ən əplɔz ə ði ɪnz peɪtʃɹənz. ðeɪ kɔl fəɹ ɪm tə kəntɪnju, bʌɾ i ʃʊk ə ɹɪɡɹɛtfəl hɛɾ ən ɹipleɪst ɪz fluɾ ɪn ɪts keɪs.

"Be glad I did not aim for the hand," Thorn noted, wiping down the flute, nodding to the cheering and applause of the inn's patrons. They called for him to continue, but he shook a regretful head and replaced his flute in its case.

"aɪ ɔlmoʊst wɪʃ jə wəd hæv," mæt sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz kʌf ən stɪkɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ θɹu ðə hoʊlz.

"I almost wish you would have," Mat said, raising his cuff and sticking a finger through the holes.

"blʌd wəd nɑɾ əv ʃoʊn ðət mʌtʃ ɑn ðə blæk, bʌt ðə stɪtʃɪŋ wɪl bi ɑbviəs. dʒʌs kəz jə wɛɹ mɔɹ pætʃəz ðən kloʊk dʌzn min aɪ wɑnə ɪməteɪt ju."

"Blood would not have shown that much on the black, but the stitching will be obvious. Just because you wear more patches than cloak doesn't mean I want to imitate you."

"æn jə kəmpleɪn ðət jəɹ nɑɾ ə lɔɹd," θɔɹn sɛd, linɪŋ daʊn tə kəlɛkt ɪz ɝnɪŋz.

"And you complain that you're not a lord," Thorn said, leaning down to collect his earnings.

"aɪm nɑt!" mæt sɛd. "ænd nɛvɝ maɪnd wʌt tuɑn sɛd, bɝn ju. ɪm noʊ blʌɾi noʊbəlmən."

"I'm not!" Mat said. "And never mind what Tuon said, burn you. I'm no bloody nobleman."

"ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə fɑɹmɝ kəmpleɪnɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz koʊt stɪtʃɪz wəd ʃoʊ?"

"Ever heard of a farmer complaining that his coat stitches would show?"

"ju doʊn əv tə bi ə lɔɹd tə wɑnə dʒɹɛs wɪð səm sɛns," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld.

"You don't have to be a lord to want to dress with some sense," Mat grumbled.

θɔɹn læft, slæpɪŋ ɪm ɑn ðə bæk ən hɑpɪŋ daʊn. "aɪm sɑɹi, mæt. aɪ muv baɪ ɪnstɪŋkt, dɪdn ɹilaɪz ɪt wɑz jə əntɪl aɪ sɔ ðə feɪs ətætʃt tə ði ɑɹm. baɪ ðɛn, ðə naɪf wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi aʊɾ ə maɪ fɪŋɡɝz."

Thorn laughed, slapping him on the back and hopping down. "I'm sorry, Mat. I moved by instinct, didn't realize it was you until I saw the face attached to the arm. By then, the knife was already out of my fingers."

mæt saɪd. "θɔɹn," hi sɛd ɡɹɪmli, "æn oʊl fɹɛn ɪz ɪn taʊn. wʌn u livz foʊks dɛd wɪð ðɛɹ θɹoʊts ɹɪp klin aʊt."

Mat sighed. "Thorn," he said grimly, "an old friend is in town. One who leaves folks dead with their throats ripped clean out."

θɔɹn nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ tʃɹʌbəld. "aɪ hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt fɹəm səm ɡɑɹdzmɪn dʊɹɪŋ maɪ bɹeɪk. ən wɝ stʌk hɪɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ənlɛs jə dɪsaɪd . . ."

Thorn nodded, looking troubled. "I heard about it from some Guardsmen during my break. And we're stuck here in the city unless you decide . . ."

"aɪm nɑɾ oʊpənɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ," mæt sɛd. "vɛɹɪn cʊɾə lɛft ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fəɹ mi tə kɹɔl ɔl ðə weɪ tə fɑlm ɑn maɪ hænz, ən aɪd blʌɾi hæv tə də ɪt! aɪ noʊ jə heɪt ðə dɪleɪ, bʌt ðət lɛɾɝ kəd meɪk ə mʌtʃ wɝs dɪleɪ."

"I'm not opening the letter," Mat said. "Verin could have left instructions for me to crawl all the way to Falme on my hands, and I'd bloody have to do it! I know you hate the delay, but that letter could make a much worse delay."

θɔɹn nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli.

Thorn nodded reluctantly.

"lɛts ɡɛt bæk tə kæmp," mæt sɛd.

"Let's get back to camp," Mat said.

ðə bænz kæmp wɑz ə liɡ aʊtsaɪɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn. θɔɹn ən mæt hæd nɑt ɹɪɾən ɪn - wɔkɝz wɝ lɛs kənspɪkjuəs, ən mæt wəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɔɹsəz ɪndə ðə sɪɾi əntɪl i faʊn ə steɪbəl ðəɾ i tʃɹʌstɪd. ðə pɹaɪs ʌv ɡʊd hɔɹsəz wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɪdɪkjələs. hi hæd hoʊp tə liv ðət bɪhaɪnd wʌns i lɛf sintʃæn lænz, bʌɾ ɪleɪnz ɑɹmiz wɝ baɪɪŋ ʌp ɛvɹi ɡʊd hɔɹs ðeɪ kəd faɪnd, ən moʊst ə ðə nɑt-soʊ-ɡʊd wʌnz, tu. bɪɑn ðæt, hi hæd hɝd ðət hɔɹsəz hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ðiz deɪz. mit wɑz mit, ən pipəl wɝ kloʊs tə stɑɹvɪŋ, ivən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɪt meɪd mæts skɪn kɹɔl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə tʃɹuθ.

The Band's camp was a league outside of Caemlyn. Thorn and Mat had not ridden in - walkers were less conspicuous, and Mat would not bring horses into the city until he found a stable that he trusted. The price of good horses was getting ridiculous. He had hoped to leave that behind once he left Seanchan lands, but Elayne's armies were buying up every good horse they could find, and most of the not-so-good ones, too. Beyond that, he had heard that horses had a way of disappearing these days. Meat was meat, and people were close to starving, even in Caemlyn. It made Mat's skin crawl, but it was the truth.

hi ən θɔɹn spɛn ðə wɔk bæk tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɡboʊləm, dəsaɪɾɪŋ vɛɹi lɪɾəl ʌðɝ ðən tə meɪk ɛvɹiwʌn əlɝɾ ən əv mæt stɑɹt slipɪŋ ɪn ə dɪfɹən tɛn ɛvɹi naɪt.

He and Thorn spent the walk back talking about the gbolam, deciding very little other than to make everyone alert and have Mat start sleeping in a different tent every night.

mæt ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz ðə tu ʌv əm kɹɛstəɾ ə hɪltɑp. keɪɛmlɪn wɑz əbleɪz wɪð ðə laɪɾ ə tɔɹtʃɪz ən læmps. ɪluməneɪʃən hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi laɪk ə fɑɡ, ɡɹæn spaɪɹz ən taʊɝz lɪt baɪ ðə ɡloʊ. ði oʊl mɛmɹiz ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðɪs sɪɾi - ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əsɔltɪŋ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ændɝ wɑz ivən ə neɪʃən. keɪɛmlɪn hæd nɛvɝ meɪd fəɹ ən izi faɪt. hi dɪd nɑɾ ɛnvi ðə haʊsəz ðət hæd tʃɹaɪd tə siz ɪt fɹəm ɪleɪn.

Mat glanced over his shoulder as the two of them crested a hilltop. Caemlyn was ablaze with the light of torches and lamps. Illumination hung over the city like a fog, grand spires and towers lit by the glow. The old memories inside him remembered this city - remembered assaulting it before Andor was even a nation. Caemlyn had never made for an easy fight. He did not envy the Houses that had tried to seize it from Elayne.

θɔɹn stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm. "ɪt simz laɪk fɝɛvɝ sɪns wi lɛf hɪɹ læst, dʌzn ɪt, mæt?"

Thorn stepped up beside him. "It seems like forever since we left here last, doesn't it, Mat?"

"bɝn mi, bʌɾ ɪt dʌz," mæt sɛd. "wʌɾ ɛvɝ kənvɪnst əs tə ɡoʊ hʌnt-ɪŋ ðoʊz ful ɡɝlz? nɛks taɪm, ðeɪ kən seɪv ðɛmsɛlvz."

"Burn me, but it does," Mat said. "What ever convinced us to go hunt-ing those fool girls? Next time, they can save themselves."

θɔɹn aɪd hɪm. "ɑɹənt wi əbaʊt tə də ðə seɪm θɪŋ? wən wi ɡoʊ tə ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ?"

Thorn eyed him. "Aren't we about to do the same thing? When we go to the Tower of Ghenjei?"

ɪts dɪfɹənt. wi kæn liv əɹ wɪð ðɛm. ðoʊz sneɪks ən fɑksəz - "

It's different. We can't leave her with them. Those snakes and foxes - "

"aɪm nɑt kəmpleɪnɪŋ, mæt," θɔɹn sɛd. "aɪm dʒʌs θɔtfəl."

"I'm not complaining, Mat," Thorn said. "I'm just thoughtful."

θɔɹn sim θɔtfəl ə lɑt, leɪtli. moʊpɪŋ ɝaʊnd, kɝɛsɪŋ ðət wɔɹn lɛɾɝ fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə lɛɾɝ. "kʌm ɑn," mæt sɛd, tɝn-ɪŋ bæk əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd. "ju wɝ tɛlɪŋ mi əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn tə si ðə kwin?"

Thorn seemed thoughtful a lot, lately. Moping around, caressing that worn letter from Moiraine. It was only a letter. "Come on," Mat said, turn-ing back along the road. "You were telling me about getting in to see the Queen?"

θɔɹn dʒɔɪn ɪm ɑn ðə dɑɹk ɹoʊdweɪ. "aɪm nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd ʃi hæzən ɹɪplaɪd tə ju, mæt. ʃiz pɹɑbli ɡɑɾ əɹ hænz fʊl. wɝɾ ɪz ðət tʃɹoʊl-lɑks əv ɪnveɪɾəd ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz ɪn fɔɹs, ən ændɝ ɪz stɪl fɹæktʃɝd fɹəm ðə səksɛʃən. ɪleɪn - "

Thorn joined him on the dark roadway. "I'm not surprised she hasn't replied to you, Mat. She's probably got her hands full. Word is that Trol-locs have invaded the Borderlands in force, and Andor is still fractured from the Succession. Elayne - "

"du juv ɛni ɡʊd nuz, θɔɹn?" mæt sɛd. "tɛl mi sʌm, ɪf jə du. aɪv ə maɪn fəɹ ɪt."

"Do you have any good news, Thorn?" Mat said. "Tell me some, if you do. I've a mind for it."

"aɪ wɪʃ ðət ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ wɝ stɪl oʊpən. ɡɪl ɔlweɪz hæd tɪdbɪts tə ʃɛɹ."

"I wish that The Queen's Blessing were still open. Gill always had tidbits to share."

"ɡʊd nuz," mæt pɹɑɾɪd əɡɛn.

"Good news," Mat prodded again.

"ɔl ɹaɪt. wɛl, ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ ɪz ɹaɪt wɛɹ doʊmən sɛd. aɪ hæv wɝd fɹəm θɹi ʌðɝ ʃɪps kæptənz. ɪts pæst ən oʊpən pleɪn sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz nɔɹθwɛst ʌv waɪtbɹɪdʒ."

"All right. Well, the Tower of Ghenjei is right where Domon said. I have word from three other ship's captains. It's past an open plain several hundred miles northwest of Whitebridge."

mæt nɑɾəd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. hi fɛlt laɪk i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə taʊɝ. ə sɪlvɝi stʃɹʌktʃɝ, ənnætʃɹəl, ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ə tʃɹɪp ɑn ə boʊt, wɔɾɝ læpɪŋ ət ðə saɪdz. beɪl doʊmənz θɪk ɪliɑnɝ æksɛnt. . .

Mat nodded, rubbing his chin. He felt like he could remember something of the tower. A silvery structure, unnatural, in the distance. A trip on a boat, water lapping at the sides. Bayle Domon's thick Illianer accent. . .

ðoʊz ɪmədʒəz wɝ veɪɡ tə mæt; hɪz mɛmɹiz ə ðə taɪm wɝ fʊl ə mɔɹ hoʊlz ðən wʌn ə dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝz æləbaɪz. beɪl doʊmən hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə tɛl əm wɛɹ tə faɪn ðə taʊɝ, bʌt mæt wɑntəd kɑnfɝmeɪʃən. ðə weɪ doʊmən baʊɾ ən skɹeɪp fəɹ laɪlwɪn meɪd mæt ɪtʃ. niðɝ ʃoʊd mæt mʌtʃ əfɛkʃən, fəɹ ɔl ðə fæk ðəɾ i hæd seɪv ðɛm. nɑt ðəɾ i hæd wɑntəɾ ɛni əfɛkʃən fɹəm laɪlwɪn. kɪsɪŋ əɹ wəd bi əbaʊɾ əz fʌn əz kɪsɪŋ ə stoʊnioʊks bɑɹk.

Those images were vague to Mat; his memories of the time were full of more holes than one of Jori Congar's alibis. Bayle Domon had been able to tell them where to find the tower, but Mat wanted confirmation. The way Domon bowed and scraped for Leilwin made Mat itch. Neither showed Mat much affection, for all the fact that he had saved them. Not that he had wanted any affection from Leilwin. Kissing her would be about as fun as kissing a stoneoak's bark.

"ju θɪŋk doʊmənz dɪskɹɪpʃən wɪl bi ɪnʌf fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə meɪk əs wʌn ə ðoʊz ɡeɪtweɪz ðɛɹ?" mæt æskt.

"You think Domon's description will be enough for someone to make us one of those gateways there?" Mat asked.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," θɔɹn sɛd. "ðoʊ ðæts ə sɛkəndɛɹi pɹɑbləm, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk. wɛɹ ɑɹ wi gɑnə faɪn sʌmwʌn tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ? vɛɹɪn əz vænɪʃt."

"I don't know," Thorn said. "Though that's a secondary problem, I should think. Where are we going to find someone to make a gateway? Verin has vanished."

"aɪl faɪn ə weɪ."

"I'll find a way."

"ɪf jə doʊnt, wɪl ɛn ʌp spɛndɪŋ wiks tʃɹævlɪŋ tə ðə pleɪs,' θɔɹn sɛd. "aɪ doʊn laɪk - "

"If you don't, we'll end up spending weeks traveling to the place,' Thorn said. "I don't like - "

"aɪl faɪn əs ə ɡeɪtweɪ," mæt sɛd fɝmli. "meɪbi vɛɹɪn wɪl kʌm bæk ən ɹilis mi fɹəm ðɪs blʌɾi oʊθ."

"I'll find us a gateway," Mat said firmly. "Maybe Verin will come back and release me from this bloody oath."

"bɛs ðət wʌn steɪz əweɪ," θɔɹn sɛd. "aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs hɝ. ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ ɔf əbaʊt ðət wʌn."

"Best that one stays away," Thorn said. "I don't trust her. There's something off about that one."

"ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ," mæt sɛd. "ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ ɔf əbaʊɾ əm ɔl -  laɪk daɪs wɛɹ ðə pɪps doʊn æɾ ʌp - bʌt fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ kaɪndə laɪk vɛɹɪn. ən ɪm ə ɡʊd dʒʌdʒ ə kɛɹɪktɝ, jə noʊ ðæt."

"She's Aes Sedai," Mat said. "There's something off about them all -  like dice where the pips don't add up - but for an Aes Sedai, I kind of like Verin. And I'm a good judge of character, you know that."

θɔɹn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. mæt skaʊl bæk.

Thorn raised an eyebrow. Mat scowled back.

"iðɝ weɪ," θɔɹn sɛd, "wi ʃəd pɹɑbli stɑɹt sɛndɪŋ ɡɑɹdz wɪð jə wən jə vɪzət ðə sɪɾi."

"Either way," Thorn said, "we should probably start sending guards with you when you visit the city."

"ɡɑɹdz woʊn hɛlp əɡɛns ðə ɡoʊləm."

"Guards won't help against the gholam."

"noʊ, bʌt wʌɾ ə ðə θʌɡz u dʒʌmp jə ɑn jəɹ weɪ bæk tə kæmp θɹi naɪts bæk?"

"No, but what of the thugs who jumped you on your way back to camp three nights back?"

mæt ʃɪvɝd. "æt lis ðoʊz wɝ dʒʌst ɡʊd, ɑnəs θivz. ðeɪ oʊnli wɑntəd maɪ pɝs, naɪs ən nætʃɹəl. nɑɾ ə wʌn hæɾ ə pɪktʃɝ ə mi ɪn ðɛɹ pɑkəts. ən ɪts nɑt laɪk ðeɪ wɝ twɪstəd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝ tə ɡoʊ kɹeɪzi ət sʌnsɛɾ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ."

Mat shivered. "At least those were just good, honest thieves. They only wanted my purse, nice and natural. Not a one had a picture of me in their pockets. And it's not like they were twisted by the Dark One's power to go crazy at sunset or anything."

"stɪl," θɔɹn sɛd.

"Still," Thorn said.

mæt meɪd noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt. bɝn hɪm, bʌɾ i pɹɑbli ʃəd bi bɹɪŋɪŋ soʊlʒɝz wɪð hɪm. ə fju ɹɛdʒɹmz, ɛniweɪ. ðə kæmp wɑz dʒʌst əhɛd. wʌn ʌv ɪleɪnz klɝks, ə mæn neɪm nɔɹi, hæd ɡɹæntəd ðə bæn pɝmɪʃən tə kæmp ɪn keɪɛmlɪnz pɹɑksɪməɾi. ðeɪ hæd tə əɡɹi tə əlaʊ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn tə ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ɑn ə ɡɪvən deɪ, ən hæd tə kæmp ət list ə liɡ fɹəm ðə wɔlz, aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ɛni vɪlədʒəz ən nɑɾ ɑn ɛniwʌnz fɑɹmlænd.

Mat made no argument. Burn him, but he probably should be bringing soldiers with him. A few Redarms, anyway. The camp was just ahead. One of Elayne's clerks, a man named Norry, had granted the Band permission to camp in Caemlyn's proximity. They had to agree to allow no more than a hundred men to go into the city on a given day, and had to camp at least a league from the walls, out of the way of any villages and not on anyone's farmland.

tɔkɪŋ tə ðət klɝk mɛn ɪleɪn nu mæt wɑz hɪɹ. ʃi hæd tə. bʌt ʃi hæd sɛnt noʊ ɡɹiɾɪŋz, noʊ æknɑlɪdʒmən ðət ʃi oʊd mæt əɹ skɪn.

Talking to that clerk meant Elayne knew Mat was here. She had to. But she had sent no greetings, no acknowledgment that she owed Mat her skin.

əɾ ə bɛn ɪn ðə ɹoʊd, θɔɹnz læntɝn ʃoʊɾ ə ɡɹup ə ɹɛdʒɹmz laʊnʒɪŋ baɪ ðə saɪd. ɡʌfɹɪn, sɑɹdʒən ʌv ə skwɑd, stʊɾ ən səluɾəd. hi wɑz ə stɝɾi, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd mæn. nɑt tɛɹəbli bɹaɪt, bʌt kin aɪd.

At a bend in the road, Thorn's lantern showed a group of Redarms lounging by the side. Gufrin, sergeant of a squad, stood and saluted. He was a sturdy, broad-shouldered man. Not terribly bright, but keen eyed.

"lɔɹd mæt!" hi sɛd.

"Lord Mat!" he said.

"ɛni nuz, ɡʌfɹɪn?" mæt æskt.

"Any news, Gufrin?" Mat asked.

ðə sɑɹdʒən fɹaʊn tə hɪmsɛlf. "wɛl," hi sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ jə maɪt wɑnə noʊ." laɪt! ðə mæn spoʊk mɔɹ sloʊli ðən ə dʒɹʌŋk sintʃæn. "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm bæk tə kæmp tədeɪ. waɪl jə wɑz əweɪ, maɪ lɔɹd."

The sergeant frowned to himself. "Well," he said. "I think there's something you might want to know." Light! The man spoke more slowly than a drunk Seanchan. "The Aes Sedai came back to camp today. While you was away, my Lord."

"ɔl θɹi ʌv ðɛm?" mæt æskt.

"All three of them?" Mat asked.

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Yes, my Lord."

mæt saɪd. ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛni hoʊp ə ðɪs deɪ tɝnɪŋ aʊt tə bi ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən saʊɝ, ðət wɑʃt ɪɾ əweɪ. hi hæd hoʊp ðeɪ wəd steɪ ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi fəɹ ə fju mɔɹ deɪz.

Mat sighed. If there had been any hope of this day turning out to be anything other than sour, that washed it away. He had hoped they would stay inside the city for a few more days.

hi ən θɔɹn kəntɪnjud, livɪŋ ðə ɹoʊɾ ən hɛɾɪŋ daʊn ə pæθ θɹu ə fild ə blækwæsp nɛɾəlz ən naɪfɡɹæs. ðə widz kɹʌntʃt əz ðeɪ wɔkt, θɔɹnz læntɝn laɪɾɪŋ ðə bɹaʊn stɔks.

He and Thorn continued, leaving the road and heading down a path through a field of blackwasp nettles and knifegrass. The weeds crunched as they walked, Thorn's lantern lighting the brown stalks.

ɑn wʌn hænd, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə bi bæk ɪn ændɝ əɡɛn; ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs fɛlt laɪk hoʊm, wɪð ðoʊz nz ə lɛðɝlif tʃɹiz ən saʊɝɡəm. haʊɛvɝ, kʌmɪŋ bæk tə faɪn ɪt lʊkɪŋ soʊ dɛd wɑz dɪshɑɹɾənɪŋ. wʌt tə də əbaʊɾ ɪleɪn? wɪmən wɝ tʃɹʌbəlsəm. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ wɝs. kwinz wɝ ðə wɝst ə ðə lɑt. ən ʃi wɑz ɔl blʌɾi θɹi haʊ wɑz i gɑnə ɡɛɾ əɹ tə ɡɪv ɪm əɹ faʊnʒɹiz? hi hæd teɪkən vɛɹɪnz ɔfɝ ɪn pɑɹt kəz i θɔɾ ɪt wəd ɡɛɾ ɪm tə ændɝ kwɪkɝ ən ðɛɹfɔɹ tə stɑɹt wɝk ɑn ɑlʌdʒɹəz dʒɹæɡənz!

On one hand, it was good to be back in Andor again; it almost felt like home, with those nds of leatherleaf trees and sourgum. However, coming back to find it looking so dead was disheartening. What to do about Elayne? Women were troublesome. Aes Sedai were worse. Queens were the worst of the lot. And she was all bloody three How was he going to get her to give him her foundries? He had taken Verin's offer in part because he thought it would get him to Andor quicker and therefore to start work on Aludra's dragons!

əhɛd, ðə bænz kæmp sæɾ ɑn ə smɔl sɪɹiz ə hɪlz, ɛntʃɹɛntʃt ɝaʊn ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə ðɛm ət ðə sɛntɝ. mæts fɔɹs hæd mɛɾ ʌp wɪð ɛs-tin ən ði ʌðɝz ðət hæd ɡɔn əhɛd tə ændɝ, ən ðə bænd wɑz wɛl ən tʃɹuli hoʊl əɡɛn. faɪɝz bɝnd; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɹʌbəl faɪndɪŋ dɛd wʊd fəɹ faɪɝz ðiz deɪz. smoʊk lɪŋɡɝɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən mæt hɝd mɛn tʃæɾɪŋ ən kɔlɪŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑt tu leɪt jɛt, ən mæt dɪd nɑɾ ɛnfɔɹs ə kɝfju. ɪf i kəd nɑt ɹɪlæks, ət list ɪz mɛn kʊd. ɪt maɪt bi ðə læs tʃæns ðeɪ ɡɑt bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

Ahead, the Band's camp sat on a small series of hills, entrenched around the largest of them at the center. Mat's force had met up with Es-tean and the others that had gone ahead to Andor, and the Band was well and truly whole again. Fires burned; there was no trouble finding dead wood for fires these days. Smoke lingered in the air, and Mat heard men chatting and calling. It was not too late yet, and Mat did not enforce a curfew. If he could not relax, at least his men could. It might be the last chance they got before the Last Battle.

tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, mæt θɔt. wi nid ðoʊz dʒɹæɡənz. sun.

Trollocs in the Borderlands, Mat thought. We need those dragons. Soon.

mæt ɹɪtɝn səluts fɹəm ə fju ɡɑɹd poʊsts ən pɑɹɾəd wɪð θɔɹn, minɪŋ tə ɡoʊ faɪn ə bɛɾ ən slip ɑn ɪz pɹɑbləmz fəɹ ðə naɪt. əz i dɪd, hi noʊɾəd ə fju tʃeɪnʒəz i kəd meɪk tə ðə kæmp. ðə weɪ ðə hɪlsaɪdz wɝ ɝeɪnʒd, ə laɪt kævəlɹi tʃɑɹdʒ kəd kʌm ɡæləpɪŋ θɹu ðə kɔɹəɾɝ bɪtwin ðɛm. oʊnli sʌmwʌn vɛɹi boʊld wəd tʃɹaɪ sətʃ ə tæktɪk, bʌɾ i hæd dʌn dʒʌs ðət dʊɹɪŋ ðə bæɾəl ə mɛɹɪsɪn væli bæk ɪn oʊl kɔɹmændə. wɛl, nɑt mæt hɪmsɛlf, bʌt sʌmwʌn ɪn ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz.

Mat returned salutes from a few guard posts and parted with Thorn, meaning to go find a bed and sleep on his problems for the night. As he did, he noted a few changes he could make to the camp. The way the hillsides were arranged, a light cavalry charge could come galloping through the corridor between them. Only someone very bold would try such a tactic, but he had done just that during the Battle of Marisin Valley back in old Coremanda. Well, not Mat himself, but someone in those old memories.

mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, hi sɪmpli æksɛptɪd ðoʊz mɛmɹiz əz ɪz oʊn. hi hæd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ əm - noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðoʊz blʌɾi fɑksəz kleɪmd - bʌɾ i hæd peɪd fəɹ əm wɪð ðə skɑɹ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk.

More and more, he simply accepted those memories as his own. He had not asked for them - no matter what those bloody foxes claimed - but he had paid for them with the scar around his neck.

ðeɪ hæd bɪn jusfəl ɑn mɔɹ ðən wʌn əkeɪʒən.

They had been useful on more than one occasion.

hi faɪnəli ɹitʃt ɪz tɛnt, ɪntɛndɪŋ tə ɡɛt fɹɛʃ smɔlkloʊðz bɪfɔɹ faɪndɪŋ ə dɪfɹən tɛn fəɹ ðə naɪt, wən i hɝɾ ə wʊmənz vɔɪs kɔlɪŋ tə hɪm. "meɪtʃɹim kɔθən!"

He finally reached his tent, intending to get fresh smallclothes before finding a different tent for the night, when he heard a woman's voice calling to him. "Matrim Cauthon!"

blʌɾi æʃəz. hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪt. hi tɝn ɹɪlʌktənli.

Bloody ashes. He had almost made it. He turned reluctantly.

tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn wɑz nɑɾ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən, ðoʊ ʃi maɪɾ əv meɪɾ ə pæsəbəl peɪpɝbɑɹk tʃɹi, wɪð ðoʊz boʊni fɪŋɡɝz, ðoʊz nɛɹoʊ ʃoʊldɝz ən ðət ɡɔn feɪs. ʃi wɔɹ ə ɹɛd dʒɹɛs, ən oʊvɝ ðə wiks əɹ aɪz hæd lɔs moʊst ə ðə nɝvəs skɪɾɪʃnəs ʃi hæd ʃoʊn sɪns spɛndɪŋ taɪm əz ə deɪmeɪn. ʃi hæɾ ə ɡlɛɹ soʊ pɹæktəst ʃi cʊɾə wʌn ə stɛɹɪŋ kɑntɛst wɪð ə poʊst.

Teslyn Baradon was not a pretty woman, though she might have made a passable paperbark tree, with those bony fingers, those narrow shoulders and that gaunt face. She wore a red dress, and over the weeks her eyes had lost most of the nervous skittishness she had shown since spending time as a damane. She had a glare so practiced she could have won a staring contest with a post.

"meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," ʃi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm. "aɪ də bi niɾɪŋ tə spik wɪð ju."

"Matrim Cauthon," she said, stepping up to him. "I do be needing to speak with you."

"wɛl, simz ðət jəɹ duɪŋ soʊ ɔlɹɛɾi," mæt sɛd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz hæn fɹəm ɪz tɛn flæp. hi hæɾ ə slaɪt fɑndnəs fəɹ tɛslɪn, əɡɛnst ɪz bɛɾɝ dʒʌdʒmənt, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɪnvaɪɾ əɹ ɪn. noʊ mɔɹ ðən i wəɾ ɪnvaɪɾ ə fɑks ɪndə hɪz hɛnhaʊs, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə haʊ kaɪnli hi θɔɾ ə ðə fɑks ɪn kwɛstʃən.

"Well, seems that you're doing so already," Mat said, dropping his hand from his tent flap. He had a slight fondness for Teslyn, against his better judgment, but he was not about to invite her in. No more than he would invite a fox into his henhouse, regardless of how kindly he thought of the fox in question.

"soʊ aɪ də bi," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "juv hɝd ðə nuz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ?"

"So I do be," she replied. "You've heard the news of the White Tower?"

"nuz?" mæt sɛd. "noʊ, aɪv hɝd noʊ nuz. ɹumɝz, ðoʊ . . . aɪv ə bɹeɪnfəl ə ðoʊz. səm seɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz bɪn ɹiunəfaɪd, wɪtʃ ɪz wʌt jəɹ pɹɑbli tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. bʌɾ aɪv ɔlsoʊ hɝd dʒʌst əz mɛni kleɪmɪŋ ðəɾ ɪts stɪl ət wɔɹ. ən ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn fɔt ðə læs bæɾəl ɪn ɹændz pleɪs, ən ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɹeɪz ən ɑɹmi ʌv soʊlʒɝz baɪ ɡɪvɪŋ bɝθ tə ðɛm, ən ðət flaɪɪŋ mɑnstɝz ətæk ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðət læst wʌn ɪz pɹɑbli dʒʌst stɔɹiz ə ɹeɪkən dʒɹɪftɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə saʊθ. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðə wʌn əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹeɪzɪŋ ən ɑɹmi ʌv beɪbiz hoʊlz səm wɔɾɝ."

"News?" Mat said. "No, I've heard no news. Rumors, though . . . I've a brainful of those. Some say the White Tower has been reunified, which is what you're probably talking about. But I've also heard just as many claiming that it is still at war. And that the Amyrlin fought the Last Battle in Rand's place, and that the Aes Sedai have decided to raise an army of soldiers by giving birth to them, and that flying monsters attacked the White Tower. That last one is probably just stories of raken drifting up from the south. But I think the one about Aes Sedai raising an army of babies holds some water."

tɛslɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð ə flæt stɛɹ. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk əweɪ. ɡʊd θɪŋ mæts fɑðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz sɛɾ i wɑz mɔɹ stʌbɝn ðən ə fleɪmɪŋ tʃɹi stʌmp.

Teslyn regarded him with a flat stare. He did not look away. Good thing Mat's father had always said he was more stubborn than a flaming tree stump.

ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, tɛslɪn saɪd, hɝ feɪs sɔfənɪŋ. "ju bi, ʌv kɔɹs, ɹaɪtli skɛptəkəl. bʌt wi kænɑɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðə nuz. ivən idɛzinə, hu fulɪʃli saɪɾəd wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz, dʌz wɪʃ tə ɹɪtɝn. wi də plæn tə ɡoʊ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. əz ɪts jəɹ hæbət tə slip leɪt, aɪ wɑntəd tə kʌm tə jə tənaɪɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɡɪv jə maɪ θæŋks."

Remarkably, Teslyn sighed, her face softening. "You be, of course, rightly skeptical. But we cannot ignore the news. Even Edesina, who foolishly sided with the rebels, does wish to return. We do plan to go in the morning. As it is your habit to sleep late, I wanted to come to you tonight in order to give you my thanks."

"jɔɹ wʌt?"

"Your what?"

"maɪ θæŋks, mæstɝ kɔθən," tɛslɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ðɪs tʃɹɪp dɪd nɑt bi izi əpɑn ɛni ʌv ʌs. ðəɹ əv bɪn moʊməns ʌv. . . tɛnʃən. aɪ də nɑt seɪ ðəɾ aɪ əɡɹi wɪð itʃ dɪsɪʒən jə meɪd. ðət də nɑt ɹimuv ðə fæk ðət wɪθaʊt ju, aɪ wəd stɪl bi ɪn sintʃæn hænz." ʃi ʃɪvɝd. "aɪ pɹitɛnd, dʊɹɪŋ maɪ mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt moʊməns, ðəɾ aɪ wʊɾə ɹɪzɪstɪɾ əm ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɪskeɪpt ɑn maɪ oʊn. ɪt də bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə meɪnteɪn səm ɪluʒənz wɪð jɝsɛlf, wəd jə nɑt seɪ?"

"My thanks, Master Cauthon," Teslyn said dryly. "This trip did not be easy upon any of us. There have been moments of. . . tension. I do not say that I agree with each decision you made. That do not remove the fact that without you, I would still be in Seanchan hands." She shivered. "I pretend, during my more confident moments, that I would have resisted them and eventually escaped on my own. It do be important to maintain some illusions with yourself, would you not say?"

mæt ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn. "meɪbi, tɛslɪn. meɪbi ɪndid."

Mat rubbed his chin. "Maybe, Teslyn. Maybe indeed."

ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, ʃi hɛld aʊɾ əɹ hæn tə hɪm. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ʃəd jə ɛvɝ kʌm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, jə də hæv wɪmən ðəɹ u ɑɹ ɪn jəɹ dɛt, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. aɪ də nɑt fɝɡɛt."

Remarkably, she held out her hand to him. "Remember, should you ever come to the White Tower, you do have women there who are in your debt, Matrim Cauthon. I do not forget."

hi tʊk ðə hænd. ɪt fɛlt əz boʊni əz ɪt lʊkt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wɔɹmɝ ðən i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. səm ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ aɪs ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ veɪnz, ðət wɑz fəɹ sɝɾən. bʌɾ ʌðɝz wɝ nɑt soʊ bæd.

He took the hand. It felt as bony as it looked, but it was warmer than he had expected. Some Aes Sedai had ice running in their veins, that was for certain. But others were not so bad.

ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɪm. ə ɹɪspɛkfəl nɑd. ɔlmoʊst ə baʊ. mæt ɹilist əɹ ænd, filɪŋ əz ənsɛɾəld əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd kɪkt ɪz lɛɡz aʊt fɹəm ʌn-dɝniθ hɪm. ʃi tɝn tə wɔk bæk təwɔɹɾ əɹ oʊn tɛnt.

She nodded to him. A respectful nod. Almost a bow. Mat released her and, feeling as unsettled as if someone had kicked his legs out from un-derneath him. She turned to walk back toward her own tent.

jəl bi niɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz," hi sɛd. "ɪf jə weɪt tə liv əntɪl aɪ ɡɛɾ ʌp ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əl ɡɪv jə sʌm. ən səm pɹəvɪʒənz. wʊdn də fəɹ jə tə stɑɹv bɪfɔɹ jə ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən fɹəm wʌt wiv sin leɪtli ðə vɪlədʒəz jəl pæs woʊn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə spɛɹ."

You'll be needing horses," he said. "If you wait to leave until I get up in the morning, I'll give you some. And some provisions. Wouldn't do for you to starve before you get to Tar Valon, and from what we've seen lately the villages you'll pass won't have anything to spare."

"ju toʊl dʒoʊlin - "

"You told Joline - "

"aɪ kaʊntəd maɪ hɔɹsəz əɡɛn," mæt sɛd. ðoʊz daɪs wɝ stɪl ɹætlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, bɝn ðɛm. "aɪ dɪɾ ənʌðɝ kaʊn ə ðə bænz hɔɹsəz. tɝnz aʊt wɪv səm tə spɛɹ. jə meɪ teɪk ðɛm."

"I counted my horses again," Mat said. Those dice were still rattling in his head, burn them. "I did another count of the Band's horses. Turns out we have some to spare. You may take them."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt kʌm tə jə tənaɪt tə mənɪpjəleɪt jə ɪndə ɡɪvɪŋ mi hɔɹsəz," tɛslɪn sɛd. "aɪ də bi sənsɪɹ."

"I did not come to you tonight to manipulate you into giving me horses," Teslyn said. "I do be sincere."

"soʊ aɪ fɪɡjɝd," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ lɪftɪŋ ʌp ðə flæp tə hɪz tɛnt. "ðæts waɪ aɪ meɪd ði ɔfɝ." hi stɛpt ɪndə ðə tɛnt.

"So I figured," Mat said, turning lifting up the flap to his tent. "That's why I made the offer." He stepped into the tent.

ðɛɹ, hi fɹoʊz. ðət sɛnt. . .

There, he froze. That scent. . .

blʌd.

Blood.


tʃæptɝ naɪn


CHAPTER 9

blʌɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ


Blood in the Air

mæt dʌkt ɪmiɾiətli. ðəɾ ɪnstɪŋk seɪvd ɪz laɪf əz sʌmθɪŋ swʌŋ θɹu ði ɛɹ əbʌv ɪz hɛd. mæt ɹoʊl tə ðə saɪd, hɪz hæn hɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ wɛɾ əz ɪt tʌtʃt ðə flɔɹ. "mɝɾɝ!" hi bɛloʊd. "mɝɾɝ ɪn ðə kæmp! blʌɾi mɝɾɝ!"

Mat ducked immediately. That instinct saved his life as something swung through the air above his head. Mat rolled to the side, his hand hitting something wet as it touched the floor. "Murder!" he bellowed. "Murder in the camp! Bloody murder!"

sʌmθɪŋ muv təwɔɹd hɪm. ðə tɛnt wɑz kəmplitli blæk, bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ ɪt. mæt stʌmbəld, bʌt lʌk wɑz wɪð ɪm əz əɡɛn sʌmθɪŋ swɪʃt nɪɹ hɪm.

Something moved toward him. The tent was completely black, but he could hear it. Mat stumbled, but luck was with him as again something swished near him.

mæt hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ɹoʊld, flɪŋɪŋ ɪz hæn tə ðə saɪd. hi hæd lɛft. . .

Mat hit the ground and rolled, flinging his hand to the side. He had left. . .

ðɛɹ! hi keɪm ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɪz slipɪŋ pælət, hɪz hænd ɡɹæspɪŋ ət ðə lɔŋ wʊɾən hæf ðɛɹ. hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf bækwɝd tə hɪz fit, hɔlɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ʌp, ðən spʌn ən slæʃt - nɑɾ ət ðə fɔɹm muvɪŋ θɹu ðə tɛn təwɔɹd hɪm, bʌɾ ət ðə wɔl.

There! He came up beside his sleeping pallet, his hand grasping at the long wooden haft there. He threw himself backward to his feet, hauling the ashandarei up, then spun and slashed - not at the form moving through the tent toward him, but at the wall.

ðə fæbɹɪk kʌɾ izəli ən mæt lɛpt aʊt, klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ-bleɪɾɪd spɪɹ ɪn wʌn hænd. wɪð ɪz ʌðɝ hænd, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə lɛðɝ stʃɹæp əɾ ɪz nɛk, hɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɹɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz skɪn ɪn ɪz heɪst.

The fabric cut easily and Mat leaped out, clutching his long-bladed spear in one hand. With his other hand, he reached for the leather strap at his neck, his fingernails ripping at his skin in his haste.

hi pʊl ðə fɑks-hɛd mədæljən ɔf ən tɝn ɪn ðə bɹʌʃ aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛnt.

He pulled the fox-head medallion off and turned in the brush outside the tent.

ə wik laɪt keɪm fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ læntɝn ɑn ə poʊst əɾ ən ɪntɝsɛkʃən ə kæmp pæθweɪz. baɪ ɪt, mæt meɪɾ aʊt ðə fɪɡjɝ slaɪɾɪŋ aʊt ðə ɹɪp ɪn ðə tɛnt. ə fɪɡjɝ i hæd fɪɹd tə si. ðə ɡoʊləm lʊk laɪk ə mæn, slɛndɝ wɪð sændi hɛɹ ən ənɹɪmɑɹkəbəl fitʃɝz. ði oʊnli θɪŋ dɪstɪŋkt əbaʊt ðə θɪŋ wɑz ðə skɑɹ ɑn ɪts tʃik.

A weak light came from a nearby lantern on a post at an intersection of camp pathways. By it, Mat made out the figure sliding out the rip in the tent. A figure he had feared to see. The gholam looked like a man, slender with sandy hair and unremarkable features. The only thing distinct about the thing was the scar on its cheek.

ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə lʊk hɑɹmləs, səpoʊz tə bi fɔɹɡɛɾəbəl. ɪf moʊs pipəl sɔ ðɪs θɪŋ ɪn ə kɹaʊd, ðeɪ wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt. ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə pɔɪnt wɛɹ ɪt ɹɪp ðɛɹ θɹoʊɾ aʊt.

It was supposed to look harmless, supposed to be forgettable. If most people saw this thing in a crowd, they would ignore it. Right up to the point where it ripped their throat out.

mæt bækt əweɪ. hɪz tɛnt wɑz nɪɹ ə hɪlsaɪd, ən i bækt ʌp tə ɪt, pʊlɪŋ ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən ʌp ən ɹæpɪŋ ɪt taɪtli baɪ ɪts lɛðɝ stʃɹæp tə ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɛs bleɪd. ɪt wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ə pɝfək fɪt, bʌɾ i hæd pɹæktəs ðɪs. ðə mədæljən wɑz ði oʊnli θɪŋ i nu ðət kəd hɝt ðə ɡoʊləm. hi wɝk swɪfli, stɪl jɛlɪŋ fəɹ hɛlp. soʊlʒɝz wəd bi noʊ jus əɡɛns ðɪs θɪŋ, bʌt ðə ɡoʊləm hæd sɛd bɪfɔɹ ðəɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə əvɔɪd tu mʌtʃ noʊɾəs. ətɛnʃən maɪt fɹaɪɾən ɪɾ əweɪ.

Mat backed away. His tent was near a hillside, and he backed up to it, pulling the foxhead medallion up and wrapping it tightly by its leather strap to the side of his ashandarei s blade. It was far from a perfect fit, but he had practiced this. The medallion was the only thing he knew that could hurt the gholam. He worked swiftly, still yelling for help. Soldiers would be no use against this thing, but the gholam had said before that it had been ordered to avoid too much notice. Attention might frighten it away.

ɪt dɪd hɛzəteɪt, ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kæmp. ðən ɪt tɝn bæk tə mæt stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ɪts muvməns wɝ əz fluəɾ əz sɪlk ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. "ju ʃəd bi pɹaʊd," ɪt wɪspɝd. "ðə wʌn u naʊ kəntʃɹoʊlz mi wɑns jə mɔɹ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls. aɪm tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɔl ʌðɝz əntɪl aɪ hæv teɪstəd jəɹ blʌd."

It did hesitate, glancing toward the camp. Then it turned back to Mat stepping forward. Its movements were as fluid as silk rippling in the wind. "You should be proud," it whispered. "The one who now controls me wants you more than anyone else. I am to ignore all others until I have tasted your blood."

ɪn ɪts lɛf hænd, ðə kɹitʃɝ kæɹiɾ ə lɔŋ dæɡɝ. ɪts ɹaɪt hæn dʒɹɪp blʌd. mæt fɛlt ə fɹizɪŋ tʃɪl. hu hæɾ ɪt kɪld? hu ɛls hæd bɪn mɝɾɝd ɪn meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɛs stɛd? ði ɪmədʒ ə taɪlɪn flæʃt ɪn ɪz maɪn əɡɛn. hi hæd nɑt sin əɹ kɔɹps; ðə sin wɑz lɛf tə hɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən.

In its left hand, the creature carried a long dagger. Its right hand dripped blood. Mat felt a freezing chill. Who had it killed? Who else had been murdered in Matrim Cauthon s stead? The image of Tylin flashed in his mind again. He had not seen her corpse; the scene was left to his imagination.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, mæt hæɾ ə pɹɪɾi ɡʊɾ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən.

Unfortunately, Mat had a pretty good imagination.

ðəɾ ɪmədʒ ɪn ɪz hɛd, smɛlɪŋ ðə blʌɾ ɑn ði ɛɹ, hi dɪd ðə moʊs fulɪʃ θɪŋ i kəd hæv.

That image in his head, smelling the blood on the air, he did the most foolish thing he could have.

hi ətækt.

He attacked.

skɹimɪŋ ɪn ði oʊpən dɑɹknəs, mæt spʌn fɔɹwɝd, swɪŋɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ. ðə kɹitʃɝ wɑz soʊ fæst. ɪt sim tə floʊ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ɪz wɛpən.

Screaming in the open darkness, Mat spun forward, swinging the ashandarei. The creature was so fast. It seemed to flow out of the way of his weapon.

ɪt ɹaʊndəd hɪm, laɪk ə sɝkəlɪŋ wʊlf, fʊtstɛps bɛɹli meɪkɪŋ ə saʊn ɪn ðə dʒɹaɪd widz. ɪt stʃɹʌk, ɪts fɔɹm ə blɝ, ən oʊnli ə bækwɝd dʒʌmp baɪ ɹiflɛks seɪv mæt. hi skɹæmbəl θɹu ðə widz, swɪŋɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ. ɪt simd wɛɹi ʌv ðə mədæljən. laɪt, wɪθaʊt ðæt, mæt wəd bi dɛɾ ən bliɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd!

It rounded him, like a circling wolf, footsteps barely making a sound in the dried weeds. It struck, its form a blur, and only a backward jump by reflex saved Mat. He scrambled through the weeds, swinging the ashandarei. It seemed wary of the medallion. Light, without that, Mat would be dead and bleeding on the ground!

ɪt keɪm əɾ ɪm əɡɛn, laɪk lɪkwəd dɑɹknəs. mæt swʌŋ waɪldli ən klɪp ðə ɡoʊləm mɔɹ baɪ lʌk ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ðə mədæljən meɪɾ ə sɪɹɪŋ hɪs əz ɪt tʌtʃt ðə bists hænd. ðə sɛn ə bɝn flɛʃ ɹoʊz ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ðə ɡoʊləm skɹæmbəl bæk.

It came at him again, like liquid darkness. Mat swung wildly and clipped the gholam more by luck than anything else. The medallion made a searing hiss as it touched the beast's hand. The scent of burned flesh rose in the air, and the gholam scrambled back.

"ju dɪdn əv tə kɪl hɝ, bɝn ju," mæt jɛld əɾ ɪt. "ju cʊɾə lɛf hɝ! jə dɪdnt wɑn hɝ; jə wɑntəd mi!"

"You didn't have to kill her, burn you," Mat yelled at it. "You could have left her! You didn't want her; you wanted me!"

ðə θɪŋ mɪɹli ɡɹɪnd, ɪts maʊð ən ɑfəl blæk, tiθ twɪstəd. "ə bɝd mʌs flaɪ. ə mæn mʌs bɹið. aɪ mʌs kɪl." ɪt stɔk fɔɹwɝd, ən mæt nu hi wɑz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. ðə kɹaɪz ʌv əlɑɹm wɝ laʊd naʊ. ɪt hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ə fju moʊməns, bʌɾ ə fju mɔɹ, ən hɛlp wəɾ ɝaɪv. oʊnli ə fju mɔɹ moʊməns . . .

The thing merely grinned, its mouth an awful black, teeth twisted. "A bird must fly. A man must breathe. I must kill." It stalked forward, and Mat knew he was in trouble. The cries of alarm were loud now. It had only been a few moments, but a few more, and help would arrive. Only a few more moments . . .

"aɪv bɪn toʊl tə kɪl əm ɔl," ðə ɡoʊləm sɛd sɔfli. "tə bɹɪŋ jə aʊt ðə mæn wɪð ðə mʌstæʃ, ði eɪdʒɪd wʌn u ɪntɝfɪɹd læs taɪm, ðə lɪɾəl dɑɹk-skɪnd wʊmən u hoʊlz jəɹ əfɛkʃən. ɔl ə ðɛm, ənlɛs aɪ teɪk jə naʊ."

"I've been told to kill them all," the gholam said softly. "To bring you out The man with the mustache, the aged one who interfered last time, the little dark-skinned woman who holds your affection. All of them, unless I take you now."

bɝn ðət ɡoʊləm; haʊ dɪd ðə θɪŋ noʊ əbaʊt tuɑn? haʊ? ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl!

Burn that gholam; how did the thing know about Tuon? How? It was impossible!

hi wɑz soʊ stɑɹɾəld ðəɾ i bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə ɹeɪz ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ əz ðə ɡoʊləm lɛp fəɹ hɪm.

He was so startled that he barely had time to raise the ashandarei as the gholam leaped for him.

mæt kɝst, twɪstɪŋ tə ðə saɪd, bʌt tu leɪt. ðə kɹitʃɝz naɪf flæʃt ɪn ði ɛɹ. ðən ðə wɛpən dʒɝkt ən ɹɪp saɪdweɪz fɹəm ɪts fɪŋɡɝz. mæt stɑɹɾəd, ðən fɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɹæp ɝaʊn ɪm ən dʒɝk ɪm bækwɝd, aʊɾ ə ðə ɹitʃ ə ðə ɡoʊləmz swaɪp.

Mat cursed, twisting to the side, but too late. The creature's knife flashed in the air. Then the weapon jerked and ripped sideways from its fingers. Mat started, then felt something wrap around him and jerk him backward, out of the reach of the gholam's swipe.

wivz ʌv ɛɹ. tɛslɪn! ʃi stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz tɛnt, hɝ feɪs ə mæsk ə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən.

Weaves of Air. Teslyn! She stood in front of his tent, her face a mask of concentration.

"ju woʊn bi eɪbəl tə tʌtʃ ɪt dɝɛkli wɪð wivz!" mæt skɹimd əz əɹ ɛɹ dəpɑzɪɾɪd ɪm ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns fɹəm ðə ɡoʊləm. ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə blʌɾi ɹeɪz ɪm ʌp haɪ ɪnʌf, hi wʊɾə bɪn faɪn wɪð ðæt! bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ sin ən ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪf sʌmwʌn mɔɹ ðən ə peɪs əɹ soʊ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

"You won't be able to touch it directly with weaves!" Mat screamed as her Air deposited him a short distance from the gholam. If she had been able to bloody raise him up high enough, he would have been fine with that! But he had never seen an Aes Sedai lift someone more than a pace or so in the air.

hi skɹæmbəl tə ðə saɪd, ðə ɡoʊləm tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ æftɝ hɪm. ðən sʌmθɪŋ lɑɹdʒ flu bɪtwin ðɛm, kɑzɪŋ ðə ɡoʊləm tə dɑdʒ fludli. ði ɑbʒɛkt - ə tʃɛɹ! - kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə hɪlsaɪd bɪsaɪd ðɛm. ðə ɡoʊləm spʌn əz ə lɑɹdʒ bɛntʃ smæʃt ɪndə ɪt, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪt bækwɝd.

He scrambled to the side, the gholam charging after him. Then something large flew between them, causing the gholam to dodge fluidly. The object - a chair! - crashed into the hillside beside them. The gholam spun as a large bench smashed into it, throwing it backward.

mæt stɛɾid hɪmsɛlf, lʊkɪŋ ət tɛslɪn, hu wɑz ɹitʃɪŋ ɪndə hɪz tɛnt wɪð ɪnvɪzəbəl wivz ʌv ɛɹ. klɛvɝ wʊmən, hi θɔt. wivz kəd nɑt tʌtʃ ðə ɡoʊləm, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ θɹoʊn baɪ ðɛm kʊd.

Mat steadied himself, looking at Teslyn, who was reaching into his tent with invisible weaves of Air. Clever woman, he thought. Weaves could not touch the gholam, but something thrown by them could.

ðət wəd nɑt stɑp ɪt. mæt hæd sin ðə kɹitʃɝ plʌk aʊɾ ə naɪf ðət hæd bɪn ɹæmd ɪndə ɪts tʃɛst; ɪt hæd ʃoʊn ði ɪndɪfɝəns ə mæn wəd ʃoʊ ət plʌkɪŋ ə bɝ fɹəm ɪz kloʊðɪŋ. bʌt naʊ soʊlʒɝz wɝ lipɪŋ oʊvɝ pæθweɪz, kæɹiɪŋ paɪks əɹ sɔɹdz ən ʃilz. ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp wɑz biɪŋ lɪɾ ʌp.

That would not stop it. Mat had seen the creature pluck out a knife that had been rammed into its chest; it had shown the indifference a man would show at plucking a burr from his clothing. But now soldiers were leaping over pathways, carrying pikes or swords and shields. The entire camp was being lit up.

ðə ɡoʊləm ɡeɪv mæt ə ɡlɛɹ, ðən dæʃt ɔf təwɔɹd ðə dɑɹknəs aʊt-saɪɾ ə kæmp. mæt spʌn, ðən fɹoʊz əz i sɔ tu ɹɛdʒɹmz sɛt paɪks əɡɛns ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ ɡoʊləm. ɡɔɹɾɝən ən fɝdʒɪn. boʊθ mɛn u hæd sɝvaɪv ðə taɪm ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ.

The gholam gave Mat a glare, then dashed off toward the darkness out-side of camp. Mat spun, then froze as he saw two Redarms set pikes against the oncoming gholam. Gorderan and Fergin. Both men who had survived the time in Ebou Dar.

"noʊ!" mæt jɛld. "lɛɾ ɪt - "

"No!" Mat yelled. "Let it - "

tu leɪt. ðə ɡoʊləm ɪndɪfɹənli slɪd bɪtwin ðə paɪks, ɡɹæbɪŋ itʃ mænz θɹoʊɾ ɪn ə hænd, ðən kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪts fɪŋɡɝz təɡɛðɝ. wɪð ə spɪn, ɪt ɹɪp fɹi ðɛɹ flɛʃ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ boʊθ mɛn. ðən ɪt wɑz ɔf ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

Too late. The gholam indifferently slid between the pikes, grabbing each man's throat in a hand, then crushing its fingers together. With a spin, it ripped free their flesh, dropping both men. Then it was off into the darkness.

bɝn ju! mæt θɔt, stɑɹɾɪŋ tə dæʃ æftɝ ɪt. əl ɡʌt jə ən -  hi fɹoʊz. blʌɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ. fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz tɛnt. hi hæd nɪɹli fɝɡɑɾən ðæt.

Burn you! Mat thought, starting to dash after it. I'll gut you and -  He froze. Blood in the air. From inside his tent. He had nearly forgotten that.

oʊlvɝ! mæt skɹæmbəl bæk tə ðə tɛnt. ɪt wɑz dɑɹk wɪðɪn, ðoʊ ðə sɛn ə blʌd wʌns əɡɛn əsɔltɪd hɪm. "laɪt! tɛslɪn, kən jə - "

Olver! Mat scrambled back to the tent. It was dark within, though the scent of blood once again assaulted him. "Light! Teslyn, can you - "

ə ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ əpɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɪm.

A globe of light appeared behind him.

ðə laɪɾ ə hɝ ɡloʊb wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɪlumɪnɪɾ ə tɛɹəbəl sin ɪnsaɪd. ləpɪn, mæts sɝvɪŋ mæn, leɪ dɛd, hɪz blʌd dɑɹkənɪŋ ðə tɛn flɔɹ ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ blæk pul. tu ʌðɝ mɛn - ɹɪəm ən wɪl ɹiv, ɹɛdʒɹmz u hæd bɪn ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz dɔɹ - wɝ hipt ɑntu hɪz slipɪŋ pælət. hi ʃʊɾə noʊɾəst ðət ðeɪ wɝ mɪsɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ poʊst. ful!

The light of her globe was enough to illuminate a terrible scene inside. Lopin, Mats serving man, lay dead, his blood darkening the tent floor in a large black pool. Two other men - Riddem and Will Reeve, Redarms who had been guarding his door - were heaped onto his sleeping pallet. He should have noticed that they were missing from their post. Fool!

mæt fɛlt ə stæb ə sɑɹoʊ fəɹ ðə dɛd. ləpɪn, hu hæɾ oʊnli ɹisənli ʃoʊn ðəɾ i wɑz ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm neɪlzinz dɛθ. laɪt bɝn hɪm, hi hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd mæn! nɑɾ ivən ə soʊlʒɝ, dʒʌst ə sɝvɪŋ mæn, kɑntɛn tə hæv sʌmwʌn tə teɪk kɛɹ ʌv. mæt naʊ fɛl tɛɹəbəl fəɹ hævɪŋ kəmpleɪn əbaʊt hɪm.

Mat felt a stab of sorrow for the dead. Lopin, who had only recently shown that he was recovered from Nalesean's death. Light burn him, he had been a good man! Not even a soldier, just a serving man, content to have someone to take care of. Mat now felt terrible for having complained about him.

wɪθaʊt ləpɪnz hɛlp, mæt wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp ɛbu dɑɹ.

Without Lopin's help, Mat would not have been able to escape Ebou Dar.

ən ðə fɔɹ ɹɛdʒɹmz, tu ʌv hum hæd sɝvaɪvd ɛbu dɑɹ ən ðə ɡoʊləmz pɹiviəs ətæk.

And the four Redarms, two of whom had survived Ebou Dar and the gholam's previous attack.

aɪ ʃʊɾə sɛnt wɝd, mæt θɔt. ʃʊɾə pʊt ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp ɑn əlɝt. wəd ðəɾ əv dʌn ɛni ɡʊd? ðə ɡoʊləm hæd pɹuvən ɪtsɛlf pɹæktəkli ənstɑpəbəl. mæt hæd ðə səspɪʃən ðəɾ ɪt kəd kʌt daʊn ði ɪntaɪɝ bæn ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɪm, ɪf ɪt niɾəd tə. oʊnli ɪts mæstɝz kəmæn ðəɾ ɪɾ əvɔɪɾ ətɛnʃən pɹɪvɛntɪɾ ɪt fɹəm duɪŋ soʊ.

I should have sent word, Mat thought. Should have put the entire camp on alert. Would that have done any good? The gholam had proven itself practically unstoppable. Mat had the suspicion that it could cut down the entire Band in getting to him, if it needed to. Only its master's command that it avoid attention prevented it from doing so.

hi dɪd nɑt si ɛni saɪn ʌv oʊlvɝ, ðoʊ ðə bɔɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn slipɪŋ ɑn ɪz pæləɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. ləpɪnz blʌd hæd pul nɪɹbaɪ, ən oʊlvɝz blæŋkət wɑz soʊkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm. mæt tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən bɪɡæn sɝtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə ʃæmbəlz, oʊvɝtɝnɪŋ blæŋkəts ən lʊkɪŋ bɪhaɪn tʃɹævəl fɝnɪtʃɝ, wɝiɾ ət wʌɾ i maɪt faɪnd.

He did not see any sign of Olver, though the boy should have been sleeping on his pallet in the corner. Lopin's blood had pooled nearby, and Olver's blanket was soaking it up from the bottom. Mat took a deep breath and began searching through the shambles, overturning blankets and looking behind travel furniture, worried at what he might find.

mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz ɝaɪvd, kɝsɪŋ. ðə kæmp wɑz kʌmɪŋ əlɝt: hɔɹnz ʌv wɔɹnɪŋ bloʊɪŋ, læntɝnz biɪŋ lɪt, ɑɹmɝ klæŋkɪŋ.

More soldiers arrived, cursing. The camp was coming alert: horns of warning blowing, lanterns being lit, armor clanking.

"oʊlvɝ," mæt sɛd tə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɡæðɝɪŋ əɾ ɪz dɔɹweɪ. hi hæd sɝtʃt ði ɪntaɪɝ blʌɾi tɛnt! "hæz ɛniwʌn sin hɪm?"

"Olver," Mat said to the soldiers gathering at his doorway. He had searched the entire bloody tent! "Has anyone seen him?"

"aɪ θɪŋk i wɑz wɪð noʊl," sɛd sloʊn mæɾoʊ, ə waɪd-ɪɹd ɹɛdɑɹm. "ðeɪ - "

"I think he was with Noal," said Slone Maddow, a wide-eared Redarm. "They - "

mæt ʃʌvd ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt, ðən ɹæn θɹu kæmp təwɔɹd noʊlz tɛnt. hi ɝaɪv dʒʌst əz ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn wɑz stɛpɪŋ aʊt, lʊkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn əlɑɹm.

Mat shoved his way out of the tent, then ran through camp toward Noal's tent. He arrived just as the white-haired man was stepping out, looking about in alarm.

"oʊlvɝ?" mæt æskt, ɹitʃɪŋ ði oʊldɝ mæn.

"Olver?" Mat asked, reaching the older man.

"hiz seɪf, mæt," noʊl sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "aɪm sɑɹi - aɪ dɪdn min tə əlɑɹm ju. wi wɝ pleɪɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz, ən ðə bɔɪ fɛl əslip ɑn vi flɔɹ. aɪ pʊld ə blæŋkəɾ oʊvɝ hɪm; hiz bɪn steɪɪŋ ʌp soʊ leɪt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ jə ðiz naɪts ðəɾ aɪ fɪɡjɝɾ ɪt wɑz bɛs nɑt tə weɪk hɪm. aɪ ʃʊɾə sɛnt wɝd."

"He's safe, Mat," Noal said, grimacing. "I'm sorry - I didn't mean to alarm you. We were playing Snakes and Foxes, and the boy fell asleep on v floor. I pulled a blanket over him; he's been staying up so late waiting for you these nights that I figured it was best not to wake him. I should have sent word."

"jɔɹ sɑɹi?" mæt sɛd, ɡɹæbɪŋ noʊl ɪn ən ɛmbɹeɪs. "ju blʌɾi wʌndɝfəl mæn. jə seɪvd ɪz laɪf!"

"You're sorry?" Mat said, grabbing Noal in an embrace. "You bloody wonderful man. You saved his life!"

ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, mæt sæt wɪð θɔɹn ən noʊl ɪnsaɪd θɔɹnz smɔl tɛnt. ə dʌzən ɹɛdʒɹmz ɡɑɹɾəd ðə pleɪs, ən oʊlvɝ hæd bɪn sɛn tə slip ɪn tɛslɪnz tɛnt. ðə bɔɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ kloʊs i hæd kʌm tə biɪŋ kɪld. hoʊpfəli hi nɛvɝ wʊd.

An hour later, Mat sat with Thorn and Noal inside Thorn's small tent. A dozen Redarms guarded the place, and Olver had been sent to sleep in Teslyn's tent. The boy did not know how close he had come to being killed. Hopefully he never would.

mæt wɔɹ ɪz mədæljən əɡɛn, ðoʊ hi niɾəd tə faɪn ə nu lɛðɝ stʃɹæp. ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ hæd kʌt ði ʌðɝ wʌn ʌp pɹɪɾi bæd. hi wəd nid tə faɪn ə bɛɾɝ weɪ tə taɪ ɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ.

Mat wore his medallion again, though he needed to find a new leather strap. The ashandarei had cut the other one up pretty bad. He would need to find a better way to tie it on there.

"θɔɹn," mæt sɛd sɔfli, "ðə kɹitʃɝ θɹɛɾənd ju, ən jə tu, noʊl. ɪt dɪdn mɛnʃən oʊlvɝ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd mɛnʃən tuɑn."

"Thorn," Mat said softly, "the creature threatened you, and you too, Noal. It didn't mention Olver, but it did mention Tuon."

"haʊ wəd ðə θɪŋ noʊ əbaʊt hɝ?" tɑm æskt, skɹætʃɪŋ əɾ ɪz hɛd.

"How would the thing know about her?" Thom asked, scratching at his head.

"ðə ɡɑɹdz faʊn ənʌðɝ kɔɹps aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə kæmp. dɛɹi." dɛɹi wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ u hæd ɡɔn mɪsɪŋ ə fju deɪz bæk, ən mæt hæd pɹəzumd ɪm tə hæv dɪzɝɾɪd. ɪt hæpən səmtaɪmz, ðoʊ dɪzɝʃən wɑz ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪn ðə bænd. "hid bɪn dɛɾ ə fju deɪz."

"The guards found another corpse outside of the camp. Derry." Derry was a soldier who had gone missing a few days back, and Mat had presumed him to have deserted. It happened sometimes, though desertion was irregular in the Band. "He'd been dead a few days."

"ɪt tʊk ɪm ðət lɔŋ əɡoʊ?" noʊl sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. noʊlz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ stupt ən i hæɾ ə noʊz ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ, bɛn pɛpɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊt ðə mɪɾəl ə hɪz feɪs. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz lʊkt . . . wɔɹn tə mæt. hɪz hænz wɝ soʊ nɑɹld, ðeɪ sim tə bi ɔl nʌkəlz.

"It took him that long ago?" Noal said, frowning. Noal's shoulders were stooped and he had a nose the shape of a large, bent pepper growing right out the middle of his face. He had always looked . . . worn to Mat. His hands were so gnarled, they seemed to be all knuckles.

"ɪt mʌst əv ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪd hɪm," mæt sɛd. "faʊn aʊt pipəl aɪ spɛn taɪm wɪð, wɛɹ maɪ tɛnt wɑz."

"It must have interrogated him," Mat said. "Found out people I spent time with, where my tent was."

"ɪz ðə θɪŋ keɪpəbəl ə ðæt?" tɑm sɛd. "ɪt simd mɔɹ laɪk ə haʊn tə mi, hʌntɪŋ jə aʊt."

"Is the thing capable of that?" Thom said. "It seemed more like a hound to me, hunting you out."

ɪt nu wɛɹ tə faɪn mi ɪn taɪlɪnz pæləs," mæt sɛd. "ivən æftɝ aɪ wɑz ɡɔn, ɪt wɛn tə hɝ ɹumz. soʊ iðɝ ɪɾ æsk sʌmwʌn, əɹ ɪt wɑz əbzɝvɪŋ. wɪl nɛvɝ noʊ ɪf dɛɹi wɑz tɔɹtʃɝd, əɹ ɪf i dʒʌst ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə ɡoʊləm waɪl ɪt wɑz snikɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kæmp ən spaɪɪŋ. bʌt ðə θɪŋ ɪz klɛvɝ."

It knew where to find me in Tylin's palace," Mat said. "Even after I was gone, it went to her rooms. So either it asked someone, or it was observing. We'll never know if Derry was tortured, or if he just ran across the gholam while it was sneaking about the camp and spying. But the thing is clever."

ɪt wʊdn æktʃəli  ɡoʊ æftɝ tuɑn, wəɾ ɪt? θɹɛɾənɪŋ ɪz fɹɛnz wɑz pɹɑbli dʒʌst ə weɪ tə ənhɪnʒ mæt. æftɝ ɔl, ðə θɪŋ hæd ʃoʊn tənaɪt ðəɾ ɪt stɪl hæɾ ɔɹɾɝz tə əvɔɪd tu mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən. ðət dɪdn kɑnsoʊl mæt mʌtʃ. ɪf ðət mɑnstɝ hɝt tuɑn . . .

It wouldn't actually go after Tuon, would it? Threatening his friends was probably just a way to unhinge Mat. After all, the thing had shown tonight that it still had orders to avoid too much attention. That didn't console Mat much. If that monster hurt Tuon . . .

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət dɪdn hæpən.

There was only one way to make sure that didn't happen.

"soʊ wʌt də wi du?" noʊl æskt.

"So what do we do?" Noal asked.

"wɝ gɑnə hʌn ɪt," mæt sɛd sɔfli, "ænd wɝ gɑnə kɪl ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ."

"We're going to hunt it," Mat said softly, "and we're going to kill the bloody thing."

noʊl ən θɔɹn fɛl saɪlənt.

Noal and Thorn fell silent.

"aɪ woʊn əv ðɪs θɪŋ tʃeɪsɪŋ əs ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛn-dʒeɪaɪ," mæt sɛd.

"I won't have this thing chasing us all the way to the Tower of Ghen-jei," Mat said.

"bʌt kən ɪt bi kɪld, mæt?" tɑm æskt.

"But can it be killed, Mat?" Thom asked.

"ɛniθɪŋ kən bi kɪld," mæt sɛd. "tɛslɪn pɹuv ðət ʃi kəd stɪl hɝɾ ɪt juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɪf ʃi wɑz klɛvɝ. wɪl əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ sɪməlɝ."

"Anything can be killed," Mat said. "Teslyn proved that she could still hurt it using the One Power, if she was clever. We'll have to do something similar."

"wʌt?" noʊl æskt.

"What?" Noal asked.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ jɛt," mæt sɛd. "aɪ wɑn jə tu tə kəntɪnju jəɹ pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz; ɡɛɾ əs ɹɛɾi soʊ ðət wi kən liv fəɹ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ əz sun əz maɪ oʊθ tə vɛɹɪn wɪl lɛɾ ʌs. bɝn mi, aɪ stɪl nid tə tɔk tə ɪleɪn. aɪ wɑn ɑlʌdʒɹəz dʒɹæɡənz stɑɹɾəd. əl əv tə ɹaɪɾ əɹ ənʌðɝ lɛɾɝ. stʃɹɔŋɝ, ðɪs taɪm.

"I don't know yet," Mat said. "I want you two to continue your preparations; get us ready so that we can leave for the Tower of Ghenjei as soon as my oath to Verin will let us. Burn me, I still need to talk to Elayne. I want Aludra's dragons started. I'll have to write her another letter. Stronger, this time.

"fɔɹ naʊ, wɝ gɑnə meɪk səm tʃeɪnʒəz. aɪm gɑnə stɑɹt slipɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ə dɪfɹən ɪn itʃ naɪt. wɪl lɛt ðə bænd noʊ ɪt, soʊ ɪf ðə ɡoʊləm lɪsənz, ɪɾəl faɪn aʊt. ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ nid fəɹ ɪt tə ətæk ðə mɛn.

"For now, we're going to make some changes. I'm going to start sleeping in the city. A different inn each night. We'll let the Band know it, so if the gholam listens, it will find out. There will be no need for it to attack the men.

"ju tu wɪl nid tə muv tə ðə sɪɾi tu. əntɪl ðɪs ɪz dʌn, əntɪl ɪts dɛɾ əɹ aɪ æm. ðə kwɛstʃən ɪz wʌt tə də əbaʊɾ oʊlvɝ. ðə θɪŋ dɪdn mɛnʃən hɪm, bʌt . . ."

"You two will need to move to the city too. Until this is done, until it is dead or I am. The question is what to do about Olver. The thing didn't mention him, but . . ."

hi sɔ ʌndɝstændɪŋ ɪn θɔɹnz ən noʊlz aɪz. mæt hæd lɛf taɪlɪn bɪhaɪnd, ən ʃi wɑz dɛd naʊ. hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə də ðə seɪm tə oʊlvɝ.

He saw understanding in Thorn's and Noal's eyes. Mat had left Tylin behind, and she was dead now. He was not going to do the same to Olver.

"wil əv tə teɪk ðə bɔɪ wɪð ʌs," tɑm sɛd. "iðɝ ðəɾ əɹ sɛn ɪm əweɪ."

"We'll have to take the boy with us," Thom said. "Either that or send him away."

"aɪ hɝd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tɔkɪŋ ɝliɝ," noʊl sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz feɪs wɪð ə boʊni fɪŋɡɝ. "ðeɪɹ plænɪŋ tə liv. meɪbi sɛn ɪm wɪð ðɛm?"

"I heard the Aes Sedai talking earlier," Noal said, rubbing his face with a bony finger. "They're planning to leave. Maybe send him with them?"

mæt ɡɹɪməst. ðə weɪ oʊlvɝ lɪɹɾ ət wɪmən, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ əv ɪm stʃɹʌŋ ʌp baɪ hɪz toʊz ɪn ə deɪ flæt. mæt wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ɪt hæd nɑt hæpən ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪf i ɛvɝ faʊn aʊt wɪtʃ ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz wɑz titʃɪŋ ðə bɔɪ tə æk ðət weɪ ɝaʊnd wɪmən . . .

Mat grimaced. The way Olver leered at women, the Aes Sedai would have him strung up by his toes in a day flat. Mat was surprised it had not happened already. If he ever found out which of the Redarms was teaching the boy to act that way around women . . .

"aɪ daʊt wid bi eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ɪm tə ɡoʊ," mæt sɛd. "hid bi aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ saɪɾ ən bæk hɪɹ ðɛɹ fɝs naɪɾ əweɪ."

"I doubt we'd be able to get him to go," Mat said. "He'd be out of their sight and back here their first night away."

tɑm nɑɾəd ɪn əɡɹimənt.

Thom nodded in agreement.

"wil əv tə teɪk ɪm wɪð ʌs," mæt sɛd. "hæv ɪm steɪ ət ði ɪnz ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. meɪbi ðæt  - "

"We'll have to take him with us," Mat said. "Have him stay at the inns inside the city. Maybe that  - "

"meɪtʃɹim kɔθən!" ðə ʃɹɪl kɔl keɪm fɹəm aʊtsaɪd θɔɹnz tɛnt.

"Matrim Cauthon!" The shrill call came from outside Thorn's tent.

mæt saɪd, ðən nɑɾəd tə ði ʌðɝ tu ən stʊɾ ʌp. hi stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə tɛn tə faɪn ðət dʒoʊlin ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝz hæd bʊlid ðɛɹ weɪ hɹaʊ ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz ən hæd nɪɹli jæŋkt oʊpən ðə tɛn flæps tə kʌm stɔkɪŋ ɪn. hɪz əpɪɹəns dʒɹu hɝ ʌp ʃɔɹt.

Mat sighed, then nodded to the other two and stood up. He stepped out of the tent to find that Joline and her Warders had bullied their way hrough the Redarms and had nearly yanked open the tent flaps to come stalking in. His appearance drew her up short.

sɛvɹəl ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz lʊkt əbæʃt ət hævɪŋ lɛɾ əɹ θɹu, bʌt ðə mɛn kəd nɑt bi bleɪmd. blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd blʌɾi də wʌt ðeɪ blʌɾi plizd.

Several of the Redarms looked abashed at having let her through, but the men could not be blamed. Bloody Aes Sedai would bloody do what they bloody pleased.

ðə wʊmən hɝsɛlf wɑz ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət tɛslɪn wɑz nɑt. slɛndɝ ən pɹɪɾi, ʃi wɔɹ ə waɪt dʒɹɛs wɪð ə dip nɛklaɪn. ʃi ɔfən smaɪld, ðoʊ ðət smaɪl bɪkeɪm θɪn-lɪpt wən ʃi tɝn ɪɾ ɑn mæt, ən ʃi hæd lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn aɪz. ðə taɪp ʌv aɪz ðət kəd sʌk ə mæn ɪn ən tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɹaʊn hɪm.

The woman herself was everything that Teslyn was not. Slender and pretty, she wore a white dress with a deep neckline. She often smiled, though that smile became thin-lipped when she turned it on Mat, and she had large brown eyes. The type of eyes that could suck a man in and try to drown him.

pɹɪɾi əz ʃi wɑz, mæt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə hɝ əz ə mætʃ fəɹ wʌn ə hɪz fɹɛnz. hi wəd nɛvɝ wɪʃ dʒoʊlin əpɑn sʌmwʌn i laɪkt. ɪn fækt, hi wɑz tu dʒɛntəlmənli tə wɪʃ əɹ ɑn moʊst ə hɪz ɛnəmiz.

Pretty as she was, Mat did not think of her as a match for one of his friends. He would never wish Joline upon someone he liked. In fact, he was too gentlemanly to wish her on most of his enemies.

bɛst ʃi steɪd wɪð fɛn ən blɹɪk, hɝ wɔɹɾɝz, hu wɝ mædmən ɪn mæts əpɪnjən.

Best she stayed with Fen and Blaeric, her Warders, who were madmen in Mat's opinion.

boʊθ wɝ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz - wʌn ʃaɪnɝən, ði ʌðɝ sɑldəiən. fɛnz tɪltəɾ aɪz wɝ hɑɹd. hi ɔlweɪz sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə mɝɾɝ; itʃ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ɪm wɑz ən ɪntɝvju tə si ɪf jə fɪt ðə kɹaɪtɪɹiə. blɝɪks tɑpnɑt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪn, ən ɡɛɾɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl tu ʃɔɹt. mæt wʊɾə mɛnʃən ðəɾ ɪt lʊkt ɹɪmɑɹkəbli laɪk ə bædʒɝz teɪl ɡlud tə hɪz hɛd, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt fil laɪk biɪŋ mɝɾɝd tədeɪ. ɪt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn ə blʌɾi ɑfəl ivnɪŋ.

Both were Borderlanders - one Shienaran, the other Saldaean. Fen's tilted eyes were hard. He always seemed to be looking for someone to murder; each conversation with him was an interview to see if you fit the criteria. Blaerics topknot was growing in, and getting longer, but it was still too short. Mat would have mentioned that it looked remarkably like a badger's tail glued to his head, except that he did not feel like being murdered today. It had already been a bloody awful evening.

dʒoʊlin foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. "ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət jəɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ə ðɪs . . . kɹitʃɝ ðəɾ ɪz tʃeɪsɪŋ jə wɝ ækjɝət." ʃi saʊndəd skɛptəkəl. hi hæd lɔs faɪv ɡʊd mɛn, ən ʃi saʊndəd skɛptəkəl. blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Joline folded her arms beneath her breasts. "It appears that your reports of this . . . creature that is chasing you were accurate." She sounded skeptical. He had lost five good men, and she sounded skeptical. Bloody Aes Sedai.

"ænd?" hi æskt. "ju noʊ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ɡoʊləm?"

"And?" he asked. "You know something about gholam?"

"nɑɾ ə θɪŋ," ʃi sɛd. "ɹəɡɑɹdləs, aɪ nid tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əl bi livɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ." ʃi lʊk hɛzɪɾənt. "aɪ wəd laɪk tə æsk ɪf jə wəd lɛn mi səm hɔɹsəz fəɹ ðə tʃɹɪp.

"Not a thing," she said. "Regardless, I need to return to the White Tower. I will be leaving tomorrow." She looked hesitant. "I would like to ask if you would lend me some horses for the trip.

wʌtɛvɝ jə kən spɛɹ. əl nɑt bi pɪki."

Whatever you can spare. I will not be picky."

noʊbɑdi ɪn taʊn wəd sɛl jə ɛni, ɛ?" mæt sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt.

Nobody in town would sell you any, eh?" Mat said with a grunt.

hɝ feɪs bɪkeɪm ivən mɔɹ sɝin.

Her face became even more serene.

wɛl, ɔl ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd. "æt lis jə æsk naɪsli ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ aɪ kən si haʊ hɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz fəɹ ju. aɪv pɹɑməst səm tə tɛslɪn ɔlɹɛɾi. juv səm tu. ɪɾəl bi wɝθ ɪt tə hæv jə blʌɾi wɪmən aʊɾ ə maɪ hɛɹ."

Well, all right," Mat said. "At least you asked nicely this time, though I can see how hard it was for you. I've promised some to Teslyn already. You have some too. It will be worth it to have you bloody women out of my hair."

θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs kəntʃɹoʊld. "haʊɛvɝ, ə wɝɾ ʌv ædvaɪs.

Thank you," she said, her voice controlled. "However, a word of advice.

kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə kʌmpəni jə ɔfən kip, jə maɪt wɑnə lɝn tə kɑn-tʃɹoʊl jəɹ læŋɡwədʒ."

Considering the company you often keep, you might want to learn to con-trol your language."

"kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə kʌmpəni aɪ kip ɔl tu ɔfən," mæt sɛd, "ɪts blʌdv əmeɪzɪŋ aɪ doʊn swɛɹ mɔɹ. ɔf wɪð ju, dʒoʊlin. aɪ nid tə ɹaɪɾ ə lɛɾɪaɪ tə hɝ ɹɔɪəl blʌɾi mædʒəsti kwin ɪleɪn ðə pɹɪm."

"Considering the company I keep all too often," Mat said, "it's bloodv amazing I don't swear more. Off with you, Joline. I need to write a lettei to Her Royal bloody Majesty Queen Elayne the prim."

dʒoʊlin snɪft. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə swɛɹ əɾ əɹ tu?"

Joline sniffed. "Are you going to swear at her too?"

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ æm," mæt mʌɾɝd, tɝnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ bæk tə θɔɹnz tɛnt "haʊ ɛls ɪz ʃi gɑnə tʃɹʌs ðəɾ ɪts ɹɪli fɹəm mi?"

"Of course I am," Mat muttered, turning to go back to Thorn's tent "How else is she going to trust that it's really from me?"


tʃæptɝ tɛn


CHAPTER 10

æftɝ ðə teɪnt


After the Taint

aɪ əɡɹi wɪð ðoʊz kaʊns," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, wɔkɪŋ ət pɛɹɪnz saɪd. ɡɹeɪɾi wɔkt ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, θɔtfəl ɪn ɪz blæk koʊt. mɑntəm ælzən ən ɑzi ælθoʊn - pɛɹɪnz tu ɡɑɹdz fəɹ ðə deɪ -  tʃɹeɪl bɪhaɪnd.
