I agree with those counts," Elyas said, walking at Perrin's side. Grady walked on the other side, thoughtful in his black coat. Montem al'San and Azi al'Thone - Perrin's two guards for the day -  trailed behind.

ɪt wɑz stɪl ɝli ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɑstɛnsəbli tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn ɡɑɹd poʊsts, bʌɾ i ɹɪli dʒʌst wɑntəd tə bi wɔkɪŋ. ðeɪd muv ðə kæmp tə ən ɛləveɪɾɪd mɛdoʊ əlɔŋ ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd. ɪt hæɾ ə ɡʊd wɔɾɝ səplaɪ ən wɑz nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə ðə ɹoʊd tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt, bʌt fɑɹ ɪnʌf bæk tə bi dɪfɛnsəbəl.

It was still early in the morning. Perrin was ostensibly checking on guard posts, but he really just wanted to be walking. They'd moved the camp to an elevated meadow along the Jehannah Road. It had a good water supply and was near enough to the road to control it, but far enough back to be defensible.

ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə mɛdoʊ, ən eɪntʃən stætʃu leɪ bɪfɔɹ ə pætʃ ə tʃɹiz. ðə stætʃu hæd fɔlən ɑn ɪts saɪd lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ən moʊst ʌv ɪt wɑz naʊ bɛɹid, bʌɾ ən ɑɹm ɹoʊz fɹəm ði ɝθ, hoʊldɪŋ ðə hɪlt ʌv ə sɔɹd. ðə bleɪd wɑz θɹʌst ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

On one side of the meadow, an ancient statue lay before a patch of trees. The statue had fallen on its side long ago, and most of it was now buried, but an arm rose from the earth, holding the hilt of a sword. The blade was thrust into the ground.

"aɪ ʃʊdn əv sɛnt ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz əhɛd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðæt lɛɾ əm bi snætʃt ʌp baɪ ðə fɝs pæsɪŋ fɔɹs."

"I shouldn't have sent Gill and the others ahead," Perrin said. "That let them be snatched up by the first passing force."

"ju kʊdn əv æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ðɪs," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "nɔɹ kəd juv æntɪsəpeɪɾəd biɪŋ dɪleɪd.

"You couldn't have anticipated this," Elyas said. "Nor could you have anticipated being delayed.

wɛɹ wəd juv lɛf ðɛm? ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ kʌmɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪnd, ən ɪf əɹ bæɾəl ət meɪɾən hædnt ɡɔn wɛl, ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz wʊɾə bɪn tʃɹæp bɪtwin tu ɡɹups ʌv ɛnəmi il."

Where would you have left them? Shaido were coming up behind, and if our battle at Maiden hadn't gone well, Gill and the others would have been trapped between two groups of enemy Aiel."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊl tə hɪmsɛlf. hɪz buɾɪd fit stʌk ə lɪɾəl ɪn ðə sɑɾən ɡɹaʊnd. hi heɪɾəd ðə sɛn ə ðət tʃɹæmpəld, stæɡnən mʌd mɪkst wɪð ɹɑɾɪŋ dɛd plæns. ɪt wɑznt nɪɹli əz bæɾ əz ðə blaɪt dɪziz, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə hɪm ðə hoʊl lænd wɑz oʊnli ə fju stɛps əweɪ fɹəm ðæt.

Perrin growled to himself. His booted feet stuck a little in the sodden ground. He hated the scent of that trampled, stagnant mud mixed with rotting dead plants. It wasn't nearly as bad as the Blight disease, but it seemed to him the whole land was only a few steps away from that.

ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ə ɡɑɹd poʊst. tu mɛn - hu bæɹən ən dɑɹl kɑplɪn__.

They approached a guard post. Two men - Hu Barran and Darl Coplin__.

stʊd wɑtʃ hɪɹ. ðəɹ wəd bi ədɪʃənəl skaʊts, ʌv kɔɹs: tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɪn tʃɹiz, meɪɾənz pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd lɝn ðəɾ ə fju mɛn ɡɪvən poʊsts ɝaʊn ðə kæmp lɛn ɛvɹiwʌn ɪnsaɪɾ ə sɛns ʌv ɔɹɾɝ.

stood watch here. There would be additional scouts, of course: Two Rivers men in trees, Maidens patrolling the ground. But Perrin had learned that a few men given posts around the camp lent everyone inside a sense of order.

ðə ɡɑɹdz səluɾəd hɪm, ðoʊ dɑɹlz səlut wɑz slɑpi. ðeɪ ɡeɪv ɔf ən ɑd mɪkstʃɝ ə sɛns  - ɹəɡɹɛt, fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. ən ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. ðət læst wʌn wɑz feɪnt, bʌt stɪl ðɛɹ.

The guards saluted him, though Darl's salute was sloppy. They gave off an odd mixture of scents  - regret, frustration, disappointment. And embarrassment. That last one was faint, but still there.

pɛɹɪnz səpoʊz dæliəns wɪð bɹəleɪn wɑz stɪl ɹisən ɪn ðɛɹ maɪnz, ən feɪlz ɹɪtɝn sim tə ɪnkɹis ðɛɹ dɪskʌmfɝt. ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wʌn dɪd nɑɾ izəli lɪv daʊn ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ ɪnfɪdɛlɪɾi.

Perrin's supposed dalliance with Berelain was still recent in their minds, and Faile's return seemed to increase their discomfort. In the Two Rivers, one did not easily live down a reputation for infidelity.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd tə ðɛm, ðən kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn. hi dɪdn də mʌtʃ fɔɹməl ɪnspɛktɪŋ. ɪf ðə mɛn nu hi wəd wɔk baɪ sʌmtaɪm itʃ deɪ, ðeɪd kip ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ɔɹɾɝ. fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. læs naɪt, hi hæd niɾəd tə pɹɑd slipɪŋ bɛɹɪn θeɪn əweɪk wɪð ɪz but, ən i wɑz ɔlweɪz kɛɹfəl tə wɑtʃ fəɹ ðə sɛn ə stʃɹɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk əmʌŋ ðɛm. hi wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæs dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ tə snik ə nɪp əɹ tu waɪl ɑn ɡɑɹd.

Perrin nodded to them, then continued on. He didn't do much formal inspecting. If the men knew he would walk by sometime each day, they'd keep themselves in order. For the most part. Last night, he had needed to prod sleeping Berin Thane awake with his boot, and he was always careful to watch for the scent of strong drink among them. He wouldn't put it past Jori Congar to sneak a nip or two while on guard.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə waɪtkloʊks əv əɹ pipəl ən əɹ səplaɪz." hi ɡɹɪməst, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə ɡɹeɪn pɝtʃəst ɪn soʊ hæbɝ gɑnə fɪl waɪtkloʊk bɛliz. "kʊd wi snik ɪn ən fɹi ðɛm?"

"All right," Perrin said. "The Whitecloaks have our people and our supplies." He grimaced, thinking of the grain purchased in So Habor going to fill Whitecloak bellies. "Could we sneak in and free them?"

"aɪ doʊn si ðə nid fəɹ snikɪŋ," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "pɑɹɾən, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌt jə sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ ðɪs ə lɑɹdʒɝ pɹɑbləm ðən ɪɾ ɪz."

"I don't see the need for sneaking," Grady said from behind. "Pardon, my Lord, but you seem to be making this a larger problem than it is."

pɛɹɪn lʊk bæk ət ðə lɛðɝi mæn. "ðeɪɹ waɪtkloʊks, ɡɹeɪɾi. ðəɹ ɔlweɪz ə lɑɹdʒ pɹɑbləm."

Perrin looked back at the leathery man. "They're Whitecloaks, Grady. They're always a large problem."

"ðeɪ woʊn əv ɛniwʌn u kən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ." ɡɹeɪɾi ʃɹʌɡd, hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əz i wɔkt. wɪð ðə blæk koʊt, ðə pɪn ən ði ɪnkɹisɪŋli soʊlʒɹlaɪk æɾətud, hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ lɛs ən lɛs laɪk ə fɑɹmɝ. "nild ɪz filɪŋ bɛɾɝ. hi ən aɪ kəd paʊn ðoʊz tʃɪlʒɹən daʊn əntɪl ðeɪ ɡɪv əs wʌt wi wɑnt."

"They won't have anyone who can channel the One Power." Grady shrugged, hands clasped behind his back as he walked. With the black coat, the pin and the increasingly soldierlike attitude, he was looking less and less like a farmer. "Neald is feeling better. He and I could pound those Children down until they give us what we want."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. hi heɪɾəd ði aɪdiə ʌv lɛɾɪŋ ði æʃəmən lus wɪð ɪmpjunɪɾi. ðə sɛn ə bɝn flɛʃ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ði ɝθ ɹɪpt əpɑɹɾ ən bɹoʊkən. ðə sɛns ə dəməaɪz wɛlz. haʊɛvɝ, hi kʊdn əfɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ dɪstʃɹækʃən laɪk meɪɾən. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs, hid ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ.

Perrin nodded. He hated the idea of letting the Asha'man loose with impunity. The scent of burned flesh in the air, the earth ripped apart and broken. The scents of Dumai's Wells. However, he couldn't afford another distraction like Maiden. If there were no other choice, he'd give the order.

nɑt jɛt, ðoʊ. ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz wɪð tɑvɝən. ðə wʊlvz, ðə waɪtkloʊks. θɪŋz i hæd bɪn aʊtʃɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ səm taɪm wɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hʌn hɪm. hid pʊʃt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən aʊɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. mɛni ʌv ðə mɛn u hæd bɪn wɪð ɪm ðən naʊ fɑloʊɾ ɪm hɪɹ.

Not yet, though. There are no coincidences with ta'veren. The wolves, the Whitecloaks. Things he had been outrunning for some time were returning to hunt him. He'd pushed the Children out of the Two Rivers. Many of the men who had been with him then now followed him here.

"pɝhæps ɪɾəl kʌm tə ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə ɡɹeɪɾi, stɪl wɔkɪŋ. "bʌt meɪbi nɑt. wiv ɡɑɾ ə lɑɹdʒɝ fɔɹs ðən ðeɪ du, ən wɪð ðət blæstəd wʊlfhɛd bænɝ faɪnəli teɪkən daʊn, ðeɪ meɪ nɑt ɹilaɪz u wi ɑɹ. wi flaɪ ðə bænɝ ə ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən, ən ðəɹ pæsɪŋ θɹu æl-liɑndɝz tɛɹɪtɔɹi. laɪkli ðeɪ sɔ ðə səplaɪz ɪn əɹ pipəlz kɑɹts ən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə 'pɹətɛk ðɛm.' səm dɪskʌʃən, pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl ɪntɪmɪdeɪʃən, meɪ bi ɪnʌf tə pɝsweɪɾ əm tə ɹɪtɝn əɹ pipəl."

"Perhaps it will come to that," Perrin said to Grady, still walking. "But maybe not. We've got a larger force than they do, and with that blasted wolfhead banner finally taken down, they may not realize who we are. We fly the banner of the Queen of Ghealdan, and they're passing through Al-liandre's territory. Likely they saw the supplies in our people's carts and decided to 'protect them.' Some discussion, perhaps a little intimidation, may be enough to persuade them to return our people."

ɛlaɪəs nɑɾəd, ən ɡɹeɪɾi sim tə əɡɹi, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn wɑzn kənvɪns baɪ hɪz oʊn wɝdz. ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd hɔntəɾ ɪm sɪns ɪz ɝli deɪz aʊɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. dilɪŋ wɪð əm hæd nɛvɝ bɪn sɪmpəl.

Elyas nodded, and Grady seemed to agree, though Perrin wasn't convinced by his own words. The Whitecloaks had haunted him since his early days out of the Two Rivers. Dealing with them had never been simple.

ɪt fɛlt laɪk ðə taɪm hæd kʌm. taɪm tə meɪk ən ɛn tə hɪz tʃɹʌbəlz wɪð ðɛm, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

It felt like the time had come. Time to make an end to his troubles with them, one way or another.

hi kəntɪnjuɾ ɪz ɹaʊnz, ɝaɪvɪŋ ət ði il sɛkʃən ə ðə kæmp. hi nɑɾəd əɾ ə pɛɹ ə meɪɾənz laʊnʒɪŋ ɑn ɡɑɹd wɪð ɹɪlækst əlɝtnəs. ðeɪ dɪdn stæn ʌp əɹ səlut - wɪtʃ suɾəd ɪm faɪn -  ðoʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑd. hiɾ əpɛɹənli ɡeɪnd ɡɹeɪt dʒi ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz baɪ ðə weɪ hid plænd, ðən əkɑmplɪʃt, ði ətæk ɑn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ.

He continued his rounds, arriving at the Aiel section of the camp. He nodded at a pair of Maidens lounging on guard with relaxed alertness. They didn't stand up or salute - which suited him fine -  though they did nod. He'd apparently gained great ji in their eyes by the way he'd planned, then accomplished, the attack on the Shaido.

ði il meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ɡɑɹd poʊsts, ən i hæd noʊ ɹizən tə ɪnspɛk ðɛm. bʌɾ i ɪnkluɾəd əm ɪn ɪz ɹaʊnz ɛniweɪ. ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪf i wɑz gɑnə vɪzət ði ʌðɝ sɛkʃənz ə kæmp, hi ʃəd də ɪt hɪɹ, tu.

The Aiel maintained their own guard posts, and he had no reason to inspect them. But he included them in his rounds anyway. It seemed that if he was going to visit the other sections of camp, he should do it here, too.

ɡɹeɪɾi stɑp sʌɾənli ən spʌn təwɔɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz' tɛns.

Grady stopped suddenly and spun toward the Wise Ones' tents.

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn æskt ɝdʒənli, skænɪŋ ðə kæmp. hi kʊdn si ɛniθɪŋ ənjuʒəwəl.

"What?" Perrin asked urgently, scanning the camp. He couldn't see anything unusual.

ɡɹeɪɾi smaɪld. "aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪv mænədʒd ɪt." hi stɑɹɾəd ɪndə ði il kæmp, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə ɡlɛɹz sɛvɹəl meɪɾənz ɡeɪv hɪm. ðeɪ maɪt vɛɹi wɛl əv tɔst ɪm aʊt, æʃəmən əɹ noʊ, ɪf pɛɹɪn hædn bɪn ðɛɹ.

Grady smiled. "I think they've managed it." He started into the Aiel camp, ignoring the glares several Maidens gave him. They might very well have tossed him out, Asha'man or no, if Perrin hadn't been there.

nild, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hiz bɪn wɝkɪŋ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt sɝkəlz. ɪf ɡɹeɪɾi hæd sin sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə wivz . . .

Neald, Perrin thought. He's been working with the Aes Sedai to figure out circles. If Grady had seen something in the weaves . . .

pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, ən sun ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə ɹɪŋ ʌv waɪz wʌn tɛns ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ði il kæmp, ði ɛɹiə bɪtwin əm dʒɹaɪd - pɝhæps baɪ wivz - ən ðə ɡɹaʊn pæk daʊn. nild, ɛdʒɹə ən mɑsʊɝi sæt ðɛɹ. feɪɡɝ nild wɑz ə jʌŋ mʊɹændiən wɪð ə mʌstæʃ ðət kɝl tə pɔɪns. hi wɔɹ noʊ pɪnz ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz blæk koʊt, ðoʊ hid laɪkli bi pɹəmoʊɾəd əz sun əz ðə ɡɹup ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðɛɹ ɪkskɝʒən. hid ɡɹoʊn ɪn paʊɝ sɪns ðeɪd bɪɡʌn.

Perrin followed, and soon they reached a ring of Wise One tents in the center of the Aiel camp, the area between them dried - perhaps by weaves - and the ground packed down. Neald, Edarra and Masuri sat there. Fager Neald was a young Murandian with a mustache that curled to points. He wore no pins on the collar of his black coat, though he'd likely be promoted as soon as the group returned from their excursion. He'd grown in Power since they'd begun.

hi wɑz stɪl peɪl fɹəm ðə sneɪkbaɪts hid teɪkən, bʌt lʊk mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən i hæɾ oʊnli ə fju deɪz bæk. hi wɑz smaɪlɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ði ɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən i smɛld ɪɡzubɝənt.

He was still pale from the snakebites he'd taken, but looked much better than he had only a few days back. He was smiling, staring at the air in front of him, and he smelled exuberant.

ə lɑɹdʒ ɡeɪtweɪ splɪt ði ɛɹ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə lid bæk tə ə pleɪs wɛɹ ðeɪd kæmp sɛvɹəl wiks əɡoʊ - ən oʊpən fild ə noʊ ɹil noʊt.

A large gateway split the air. Perrin grunted. It appeared to lead back to a place where they'd camped several weeks ago - an open field of no real note.

'ɪts wɝkɪŋ?" ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, nilɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪd nild.

'It's working?" Grady said, kneeling down beside Neald.

"ɪts bjuɾəfəl, dʒɝ," nil sɛd sɔfli. hɪz vɔɪs bɔɹ noʊ hɪn ə ðə bɹəvɑɾoʊ hi ɔfən dɪspleɪd. "aɪ kən filseɪaɪdɑɹ. ɪts laɪk aɪm mɔɹ kəmplit naʊ."

"It's beautiful, Jur," Neald said softly. His voice bore no hint of the bravado he often displayed. "I can feelsaidar. It's like I'm more complete now."

"jɔɹ tʃænəlɪŋ ɪt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You're channeling it?" Perrin asked.

"noʊ. aɪ doʊnt nid tə. aɪ kən juz ɪt."

"No. I don't need to. I can use it."

"juz ɪt haʊ?" ɡɹeɪɾi æskt, iɡɝ.

"Use it how?" Grady asked, eager.

"aɪ . . . ɪts hɑɹd tə ɪkspleɪn. ðə wivz ɑɹ seɪɾɪn, bʌɾ aɪ sim tə bi eɪbəl tə stʃɹɛŋθən əm wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ. soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪ kən meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɑn maɪ oʊn ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðəɾ aɪ kən ɪnkɹis ðə paʊɝ - ən saɪz - wɪð wʌt ðə wɪmən lɛn mi. laɪt! ɪts wʌndɝfəl. wi ʃʊɾə dʌn ðɪs mʌnθs əɡoʊ."

"I . . . It's hard to explain. The weaves are saidin, but I seem to be able to strengthen them with saidar. So long as I can make a gateway on my own it appears that I can increase the Power - and size - with what the women lend me. Light! It's wonderful. We should have done this months ago."

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ət ðə tu wɪmən, mɑsʊɝi ən ɛdʒɹə. niðɝ simd əz ɪɡzʌltən əz nild.

Perrin glanced at the two women, Masuri and Edarra. Neither seemed as exultant as Neald.

mɑsʊɝi lʊkt ə lɪɾəl sɪk, ən ʃi smɛld ə fɪɹ. ɛdʒɹə smɛl kjʊɹiəs ən wɛɹi. ɡɹeɪɾi hæd mɛnʃən ðət kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə sɝkəl ðɪs weɪ sim tə ɹikwaɪɝ ðə mɛn tə ɡeɪn kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ ðə wɪmən.

Masuri looked a little sick, and she smelled of fear. Edarra smelled curious and wary. Grady had mentioned that creating a circle this way seemed to require the men to gain control over the women.

"wil sɛn ðə skaʊɾɪŋ ɡɹup θɹu tə kɛɹhin sun, ðɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl ɪn ɪz pɑkət. "ɡɹeɪɾi, ɝeɪnʒ wɪð ði il əbaʊt ðət mɪʃən, sɛɾ ʌp ðə ɡeɪtweɪz əz ðeɪ æsk."

"We'll send the scouting group through to Cairhien soon, then," Perrin said, fingering the blacksmith's puzzle in his pocket. "Grady, arrange with the Aiel about that mission, set up the gateways as they ask."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz lɛðɝi feɪs. "aɪ ʃəd pɹɑbli lɝn ðɪs tɛknik ɹæðɝ ðən kəntɪnjuɪŋ ɑn ɹaʊnz. ðoʊ ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ əl bi wɑntɪŋ tə tɔk tə jə əbaʊt fɝst. ɪf juv ðə taɪm."

"Yes, my Lord," Grady said, rubbing his leathery face. "I should probably learn this technique rather than continuing on rounds. Though there's something I'll be wanting to talk to you about first. If you've the time."

"ɪf jə wɪʃ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, stɛpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡɹup. tə ðə saɪd, sɛvɹəl ə ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz keɪm fɔɹwɝɾ ən toʊl nild ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ tɝn tə tʃɹaɪ ðə sɝkəl wɪð hɪm. ðeɪ dɪdn ækt əɾ ɔl əz ɪf nild wɝ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ən i wɑz kwɪk tə oʊbeɪ. hid bɪn wɔkɪŋ laɪtli ɝaʊn ði il sɪns hid sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ə lɪɾəl tu fɹɪski tə ə meɪɾən ən ɛndəɾ ʌp pleɪɪŋ meɪɾənz kɪs.

"If you wish," Perrin said, stepping away from the group. To the side, several of the other Wise Ones came forward and told Neald it was their turn to try the circle with him. They didn't act at all as if Neald were in charge, and he was quick to obey. He'd been walking lightly around the Aiel since he'd said something a little too frisky to a Maiden and ended up playing Maiden's Kiss.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs əbaʊt, ɡɹeɪɾi?" pɛɹɪn æskt wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf.

"What is this about, Grady?" Perrin asked once they were a little way off.

"wɛl, nild ən aɪ ɑɹ boʊθ wɛl ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz, ɪt simz," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. "aɪ wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf aɪ maɪt. . ." hi sim hɛzɪɾənt. "wɛl, ɪf aɪ maɪɾ əv liv tə slɪp oʊvɝ tə ðə blæk taʊɝ fəɹ ən æftɝnun, tə si maɪ fæmli."

"Well, Neald and I are both well enough to make gateways, it seems," Grady said. "I was wondering if I might. . ." He seemed hesitant. "Well, if I might have leave to slip over to the Black Tower for an afternoon, to see my family."

ðæts ɹaɪt, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hiz ɡɑɾ ə waɪf ən ə sʌn. ði æʃəmən dɪdn ɔfən tɔk əbaʊt ðɛm.

That's right, Perrin thought. He's got a wife and a son. The Asha'man didn't often talk about them.

æktʃəli , hi dɪdn ɔfən tɔk əbaʊt mʌtʃ.

Actually, he didn't often talk about much.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, ɡɹeɪɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp ət ðə dɑɹkli klaʊɾəd skaɪ. "wi hæv waɪtkloʊks əhɛd, ən ðɛɹz stɪl noʊ tɛlɪŋ fəɹ ʃʊɹ ɪf ðoʊz ʃeɪɾoʊ wɪl lup ɝaʊn ən tʃɹaɪ tə æmbʊʃ ʌs. aɪm loʊθ tə bi wɪθaʊt jə əntɪl aɪ noʊ wɝ sʌmpleɪs seɪf."

"I don't know, Grady," Perrin said, glancing up at the darkly clouded sky. "We have Whitecloaks ahead, and there's still no telling for sure if those Shaido will loop around and try to ambush us. I'm loath to be without you until I know we're someplace safe."

"ɪt nidn bi fəɹ lɔŋ, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛɾ ɝnəsli. pɛɹɪn səmtaɪmz fɝɡɑt haʊ jʌŋ ðə mæn wɑz, oʊnli sɪks əɹ sɛvən jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf. ɡɹeɪɾi sim soʊ mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ɪn ðət blæk koʊt, wɪð ɪz sʌn-dɑɹkən feɪs.

"It needn't be for long, my Lord," Grady said earnestly. Perrin sometimes forgot how young the man was, only six or seven years older than himself. Grady seemed so much older in that black coat, with his sun-darkened face.

"wil faɪn ə taɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "sun. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə əpsɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl wɪv wɝɾ ʌv wʌts bɪn hæpənɪŋ sɪns wi lɛft." ɪnfɝmeɪʃən kəd bi poʊɾənt. beɪlwɝ hæd tɔɾ ɪm ðæt.

"We'll find a time," Perrin said. "Soon. I don't want to upset anything until we have word of what's been happening since we left." Information could be potent. Balwer had taught him that.

ɡɹeɪɾi nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ plækeɪɾɪd, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn hædnt ɡɪvən ɪm ɛni-θɪŋ dɛfənət. laɪt! ivən ði æʃəmən wɝ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə smɛl laɪk pipəl hoʊ sɔ hɪm əz ðɛɹ lɔɹd. ðeɪd bɪn soʊ əluf wən ðɪs ɔl bɪɡæn.

Grady nodded, looking placated, though Perrin hadn't given him any-thing definite. Light! Even the Asha'man were starting to smell like people ho saw him as their lord. They'd been so aloof when this all began.

"ju nɛvɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɪs bɪfɔɹ, ɡɹeɪɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "hæz sʌmθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd?"

"You never worried about this before, Grady," Perrin said. "Has something changed?"

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd sɔfli. pɛɹɪn ɡɑɾ ə wɪf ə hɪz sɛnt. hoʊpfəl "ɪt tʃeɪnʒd ə fju wiks bæk. bʌɾ ə kɔɹs jə doʊnt noʊ. noʊbɑdi noʊz. feɪɡɝ ən aɪ wɝn sɝɾən ət fɝst, ən wi wɝnt ʃʊɹ ɪf wi ʃəd tɛl ɛniwʌn fəɹ fɪɹ ə saʊndɪŋ dɛluʒənəl."

"Everything," Grady said softly. Perrin got a whiff of his scent. Hopeful "It changed a few weeks back. But of course you don't know. Nobody knows. Fager and I weren't certain at first, and we weren't sure if we should tell anyone for fear of sounding delusional."

"noʊ wʌt?"

"Know what?"

"maɪ lɔɹd, ðə teɪnt. ɪts ɡɔn'.'

"My Lord, the taint. It's gone'.'

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. wɑz ðɪs mædnəs spikɪŋ? bʌt ɡɹeɪɾi dɪdn smɛl mæd.

Perrin frowned. Was this madness speaking? But Grady didn't smell mad.

"ɪt hæpən ɑn ðət deɪ," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, "wɛn wi sɔ sʌmθɪŋ tə ðə nɔɹθ. maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ noʊ ɪt saʊnz ʌnbəlivəbəl, bʌɾ ɪts tʃɹu'.'

"It happened on that day," Grady said, "when we saw something to the north. My Lord, I know it sounds unbelievable, but it is true'.'

"simz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɹænd maɪɾ əv bɪn əbaʊt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən ðə kʌlɝz swɝld ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. hi bænɪʃt ðɛm. "ɪf jə seɪ ɪt, əl tʃɹʌs ju, ɡɹeɪɾi. bʌt wʌt dʌz ðɪs əv tə də wɪð ðə blæk taʊɝ ən jəɹ fæmli? jə wɑnə ɡoʊ si ɪf ʌðɝ æʃəmən əɡɹi?"

"Seems the sort of thing Rand might have been about," Perrin said, and the colors swirled in front of him. He banished them. "If you say it, I'll trust you, Grady. But what does this have to do with the Black Tower and your family? You want to go see if other Asha'man agree?"

"oʊ, ðəl əɡɹi," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. "ɪts . . . wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd, ɪm ə sɪmpəl mæn. sɔɹə, ʃiz ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə θɪŋkɝ. aɪ də wʌt nidz duɪŋ, ən ðæts ðæt. wɛl, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə blæk taʊɝ, ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðət niɾəd duɪŋ. aɪ nu wʌt wɑz gɑnə hæpən wən aɪ wɑz tɛstəd. aɪ nu ɪt wɑz ɪn mi. ɪt wɑz ɪn maɪ fɑðɝ, jə si. wi doʊn tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. ɹɛdz faʊn ɪm jʌŋ, ɹaɪɾ æftɝ aɪ wɑz bɔɹn.

"Oh, they'll agree," Grady said. "It's . . . well, my Lord, I'm a simple man. Sora, she's always been the thinker. I do what needs doing, and that's that. Well, joining the Black Tower, that was something that needed doing. I knew what was going to happen when I was tested. I knew it was in me. It was in my father, you see. We don't talk about it, but it was there. Reds found him young, right after I was born.

"wɛn aɪ dʒɔɪn ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, aɪ nu wʌt wəd hæpən tə mi. ə fju mɔɹ jɪɹz ən aɪd bi ɡɔn. maɪɾ əz wɛl spɛn əm faɪɾɪŋ. ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən toʊl mi aɪ wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ, ən ə soʊlʒɝ kæn liv ɪz duɾi. soʊ aɪ hævən æsk tə ɡoʊ bæk bɪfɔɹ naʊ. jə niɾəd mi."

"When I joined the Lord Dragon, I knew what would happen to me. A few more years and I'd be gone. Might as well spend them fighting. The Lord Dragon told me I was a soldier, and a soldier can't leave his duty. So I haven't asked to go back before now. You needed me."

"ðæts tʃeɪnʒd?"

"That's changed?"

maɪ lɔɹd, ðə teɪn ɪz ɡɔn. ɪm nɑt gɑnə ɡoʊ mæd. ðət minz . . . wɛl, aɪ ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə ɹizən tə faɪt. bʌt naʊ aɪv ɡɑɾ ə ɹizən tə lɪv, tu."

My Lord, the taint is gone. I'm not going to go mad. That means . . . well, I always had a reason to fight. But now I've got a reason to live, too."

lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðə mænz aɪz, pɛɹɪn ʌndɝstʊd. wʌt mʌst ɪɾ əv bɪn laɪk? noʊɪŋ ðət juɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡoʊ mæɾ ən nid tə bi ɛksəkjuɾəd. laɪkli baɪ jəɹ fɹɛnz, hu wəd kɔl ɪɾ ə mɝsi.

Looking into the man's eyes, Perrin understood. What must it have been like? Knowing that you'd eventually go mad and need to be executed. Likely by your friends, who would call it a mercy.

ðət wɑz wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd sɛnst ɪn ði æʃəmən ɔl əlɔŋ, ðə ɹizən ðeɪ hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz əpɑɹt, ɔfən simɪŋ soʊ sɑmbɝ. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls fɔt fəɹ laɪf. ði æʃəmən . . . ðeɪd fɔt tə daɪ.

That was what Perrin had sensed in the Asha'man all along, the reason they held themselves apart, often seeming so somber. Everyone else fought for life. The Asha'man . . . they'd fought to die.

ðæts haʊ ɹænd filz, pɛɹɪn θɔt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kʌlɝz swɝl əɡɛn ən ɪz fɹɛn əpɪɹ. hi wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪz lɑɹdʒ blæk hɔɹs θɹu ə sɪɾi wɪð mʌɾi stʃɹits, spikɪŋ wɪð nɪneɪiv, hu ɹoʊd bɪsaɪd hɪm.

That's how Rand feels, Perrin thought, watching the colors swirl again and his friend appear. He was riding his large black horse through a city with muddy streets, speaking with Nynaeve, who rode beside him.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən bænɪʃt ði ɪmədʒ. "wil ɡɛt jə hoʊm ɡɹeɪɾi," hi pɹɑməst. "jul əv səm taɪm wɪð əɹ bɪfɔɹ ði ɛn kʌmz."

Perrin shook his head and banished the image. "We'll get you home Grady," he promised. "You'll have some time with her before the end comes."

ɡɹeɪɾi nɑɾəd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ əz ə loʊ ɹʌmbəl ə θʌndɝ keɪm fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə tɔk tə hɝ, jə noʊ? ən aɪ nid tə si lɪɾəl ɡæɾɝən əɡɛn. aɪ woʊn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə læd."

Grady nodded, glancing at the sky as a low rumble of thunder came from the north. "I just want to talk to her, you know? And I need to see little Gadren again. I won't recognize the lad."

"aɪm ʃʊɹ hiz ə hænsəm tʃaɪld, ɡɹeɪɾi."

"I'm sure he's a handsome child, Grady."

ɡɹeɪɾi læft. ɪt fɛlt ɑd, bʌt ɡʊd, tə hɪɹ ðət fɹəm ðə mæn. "hænsəm? ɡæɾɝən? noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd, hi maɪt bi bɪɡ fəɹ ɪz eɪdʒ, bʌt hiz əbaʊɾ əz pɹɪɾi əz ə stʌmp. stɪl, aɪ lʌv ɪm sʌmθɪŋ fɪɹs." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, əmjuzd. "bʌɾ aɪ ʃəd bi ɔf lɝnɪŋ ðɪs tʃɹɪk wɪð nild. θæŋk ju, maɪ lɔɹd."

Grady laughed. It felt odd, but good, to hear that from the man. "Handsome? Gadren? No, my Lord, he might be big for his age, but he's about as pretty as a stump. Still, I love him something fierce." He shook his head, amused. "But I should be off learning this trick with Neald. Thank you, my Lord."

pɛɹɪn smaɪld, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ əz ə meɪɾən keɪm hɝiɪŋ ɪndə kæmp. ʃi ɹipɔɹɾəd tə ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌt spoʊk laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə lɛt pɛɹɪn hɪɹ. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd təwɔɹd kæmp. hi flaɪz ə flæɡ ʌv pis, bʌɾ i wɛɹz ðə kloʊðɪŋ ə ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt."

Perrin smiled, watching him go as a Maiden came hurrying into camp. She reported to the Wise Ones, but spoke loud enough to let Perrin hear. "There is a stranger riding along the road toward camp. He flies a flag of peace, but he wears the clothing of these Children of the Light."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz ɡɑɹdz. əz i heɪsən təwɔɹd ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kæmp, tɑɹn əpɪɹɾ ən fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðeɪ ɝaɪv dʒʌst əz ðə waɪtkloʊk əpɹoʊtʃt ðə fɝst ɡɑɹd poʊsts. ðə mæn ɹoʊɾ ə bɹɪljənt waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ, ən i kæɹiɾ ə lɔŋ poʊl wɪð ə waɪt bænɝ. hɪz waɪt kloʊðɪŋ -  meɪl wɪð ə tɑbɝɾ ʌndɝ ðə kloʊk - bɔɹ ə jɛloʊ sʌnbɝst ɑn ðə bɹɛst.

Perrin nodded, gathering his guards. As he hastened toward the front of the camp, Tarn appeared and fell in beside him. They arrived just as the Whitecloak approached the first guard posts. The man rode a brilliant white gelding, and he carried a long pole with a white banner. His white clothing -  mail with a tabard under the cloak - bore a yellow sunburst on the breast.

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə ʃɑɹp sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs mæn. deɪn bɔɹnhəld.

Perrin felt a sharp sinking feeling. He recognized this man. Dain Bornhald.

"aɪ kʌm tə spik wɪð ðə kɹɪmənəl pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," bɔɹnhəld ənaʊnst ɪn ə laʊd vɔɪs, pʊlɪŋ tə ə stɑp.

"I come to speak with the criminal Perrin Aybara," Bornhald announced in a loud voice, pulling to a stop.

"aɪm hɪɹ, bɔɹnhəld," pɛɹɪn kɔld, stɛpɪŋ aʊt.

"I'm here, Bornhald," Perrin called, stepping out.

bɔɹnhəld lʊkt ət hɪm. "ɪɾ ɪz ju. ðə laɪɾ əz dɪlɪvɝd jə tə ʌs."

Bornhald looked at him. "It is you. The Light has delivered you to us."

"ənlɛs ɪts ɔlsoʊ dɪlɪvɝd jə ən ɑɹmi θɹi əɹ fɔɹ taɪmz ðə saɪz ə ðə wʌn juv naʊ,"

"Unless it has also delivered you an army three or four times the size of the one you have now,"

pɛɹɪn kɔld, "ðɛn aɪ daʊt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðəɾ ɪɾəl mæɾɝ."

Perrin called, "then I doubt very much that it will matter."

"wi hæv ɪn əɹ pəzɛʃən pipəl u kleɪm fiəlti tə ju, eɪbɑɹə."

"We have in our possession people who claim fealty to you, Aybara."

"wɛl, jə kən lɛɾ əm ɹaɪɾ ɑn bæk tə əɹ kæmp, ən wɪl bi ɑn əɹ weɪ."

"Well, you can let them ride on back to our camp, and we'll be on our way."

ðə jʌŋ waɪtkloʊk tɝn ɪz maʊn tə ðə saɪd, skaʊlɪŋ. "wi hæv ənfɪnɪʃt bɪznəs, dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

The young Whitecloak turned his mount to the side, scowling. "We have unfinished business, Darkfriend."

"noʊ nid fəɹ ðɪs tə tɝn næsti, bɔɹnhəld," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə weɪ aɪ si ɪt, wi kən stɪl itʃ ɡoʊ əɹ oʊn weɪ."

"No need for this to turn nasty, Bornhald," Perrin said. "The way I see it, we can still each go our own way."

"ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wəd ɹæðɝ daɪ ðən liv dʒʌstəs əndʌn," deɪn sɛd, hɛn spæt tə ðə saɪd. "bʌɾ əl liv ðət fəɹ ðə lɔɹd kæptən kɑm-ændɝ tə ɪkspleɪn. hi wɪʃɪz tə si jə fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. aɪ hæv bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə mi ən tɛl jə ðət hiz weɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊɾ ə ʃɔɹt ɹaɪɾ əhɛd. hi wəd laɪk jə tə mit wɪð hɪm."

"The Children would rather die than leave justice undone," Dain said, hen spat to the side. "But I will leave that for the Lord Captain Com-ander to explain. He wishes to see you for himself. I have been ordered to me and tell you that he is waiting beside the road a short ride ahead. He would like you to meet with him."

"ju θɪŋk aɪm gɑnə wɔk ɪndə sətʃ ən ɑbviəs tʃɹæp?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You think I'm going to walk into such an obvious trap?" Perrin asked.

bɔɹnhəld ʃɹʌɡd. "kʌm əɹ də nɑt. maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ɪz ə mæn ʌv ɑnɝ, ən swɛɹz baɪ oʊθ jəl ɹɪtɝn seɪfli - wɪtʃ ɪz mɔɹ ðən aɪɾ əv ɡɪvən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. jə meɪ bɹɪŋ jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪkɛɹɛɾɪf juv ðɛm, fəɹ seɪfti." wɪð ðæt, bɔɹnhəl tɝn ɪz maʊn ən ɡæləpt əweɪ.

Bornhald shrugged. "Come or do not. My Lord Captain Commander is a man of honor, and swears by oath you will return safely - which is more than I'd have given a Darkfriend. You may bring your Aes Sedai^if you have them, for safety." With that, Bornhald turned his mount and galloped away.

pɛɹɪn stʊd θɔtfəli, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɹitʃɹit.

Perrin stood thoughtfully, watching him retreat.

"jɔɹ nɑt ɹɪli θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ, ɑɹ ju, sʌn?" tɑɹn æskt.

"You're not really thinking of going, are you, son?" Tarn asked.

"aɪd ɹæðɝ noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən u ɪm feɪsɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ænd wi dɪɾ æsk fəɹ pɑɹli. meɪbi bɑɹɡən fəɹ əɹ pipəl bæk. bɝn mi, tɑɹn. aɪ hæv tə ət lis tʃɹaɪ bɪfɔɹ ətækɪŋ ðɛm."

"I'd rather know for certain who I'm facing," Perrin said. "And we did ask for parley. Maybe bargain for our people back. Burn me, Tarn. I have to at least try before attacking them."

tɑɹn saɪd, bʌt nɑɾəd.

Tarn sighed, but nodded.

"hi mɛnʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "bʌt nɑɾ æʃəmən. əl bɛɾ i dʌznt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðɛm. ɡoʊ hæv ɡɹeɪɾi dʒɹɛs laɪk ə tu ɹɪvɝz mæn ən tɛl ɪm tə ɹipɔɹt tə mi, əlɔŋ wɪð ɡɔl ən səlɪn. æsk ɛdʒɹə ɪf ʃɪl dʒɔɪn əs tu. bʌt doʊn tɛl maɪ waɪf əbaʊt ðɪs. wi faɪv wɪl ɡoʊ ɑn əhɛɾ ən si ɪf ðə waɪtkloʊks wɪl ɹɪli mit wɪð əs pisfəli. ɪf sʌmθɪŋ ɡoʊz ɹɔŋ, wɪl əv ɡɹeɪɾi ɹɛɾi tə ɡɛɾ əs aʊt baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ."

"He mentioned Aes Sedai," Perrin said, "but not Asha'man. I'll bet he doesn't know much about them. Go have Grady dress like a Two Rivers man and tell him to report to me, along with Gaul and Sulin. Ask Edarra if she'll join us too. But don't tell my wife about this. We five will go on ahead and see if the Whitecloaks will really meet with us peacefully. If something goes wrong, we'll have Grady ready to get us out by gateway."

tɑɹn nɑɾəd ən hɝiɾ əweɪ. pɛɹɪn weɪɾəd nɝvəsli əntɪl tæm ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ɡɔl, səlɪn ən ɛdʒɹə. ɡɹeɪɾi keɪm ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, wɛɹɪŋ ə bɹaʊn wʊl kloʊk ən bɹaʊn ən ɡɹin kloʊðɪŋ bɑɹoʊd fɹəm wʌn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. hi kæɹiɾ ə lɔŋboʊ, bʌt wɔk laɪk ə soʊlʒɝ, wɪð ɪz bæk stʃɹeɪt, hɪz aɪz kin əz i lʊkt əbaʊt hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɛɹ ə deɪnʒɝ tə hɪm ðət noʊ kɑmən vɪlɪdʒɝ wəd bɛɹ. hoʊpfəli, ɪt wʊdn spɔɪl ðə dɪsɡaɪz.

Tarn nodded and hurried away. Perrin waited nervously until Tam returned with Gaul, Sulin and Edarra. Grady came a few minutes later, wearing a brown wool cloak and brown and green clothing borrowed from one of the Two Rivers men. He carried a longbow, but walked like a soldier, with his back straight, his eyes keen as he looked about him. There was a particular air of danger to him that no common villager would bear. Hopefully, it wouldn't spoil the disguise.

ðə sɪks ə ðɛm bɹoʊk əweɪ fɹəm kæmp, ən blɛsədli, feɪl dɪdn sim tə hæv hɝd wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. pɛɹɪn wəd bɹɪŋ əɹ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋɡɝ pɑɹli əɹ dɪskʌʃən, bʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd ðɪs tʃɹɪp tə bi kwɪk, ən i niɾəd tə bi eɪbəl tə muv wɪθaʊt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ.

The six of them broke away from camp, and blessedly, Faile didn't seem to have heard what was happening. Perrin would bring her if there was a longer parley or discussion, but he intended this trip to be quick, and he needed to be able to move without worrying about her.

ðeɪ wɛn ɑn fʊt, ən faʊn ðə waɪtkloʊks ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əhɛd daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. ðəɹ lʊk tə bi oʊnli əbaʊɾ ə dʌzən ə ðɛm, stændɪŋ nɪɹ ə smɔl tɛn ðət hæd bɪn sɛɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd. ðeɪ wɝ ʌpwɪnd, wɪtʃ ɹɪlæks pɛɹɪn ə lɪɾəl. hi kɑt sɛns ʌv æŋɡɝ ən dɪsɡʌst, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn fil laɪk ə tʃɹæp tə hɪm.

They went on foot, and found the Whitecloaks a short distance ahead down the road. There looked to be only about a dozen of them, standing near a small tent that had been set up beside the road. They were upwind, which relaxed Perrin a little. He caught scents of anger and disgust, but it didn't feel like a trap to him.

əz i ən ði ʌðɝz nɪɹd, sʌmwʌn stɛp fɹəm ðə smɔl tɛnt, wɛɹɪŋ waɪt. ðə tɔl mæn hæd faɪn fitʃɝz ən ʃɔɹt, dɑɹk hɛɹ. moʊst wɪmən wəd pɹɑbli kɔl ɪm hænsəm. hi smɛld . . . bɛɾɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ waɪtkloʊks. ðeɪ hæɾ ə waɪl sɛn tə ðɛm, laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ə ɹæbɪɾ ænəməl. ðɪs liɾɝ ə ðɛɹz smɛl kɑm, ən nɑt sɪkli əɾ ɔl.

As he and the others neared, someone stepped from the small tent, wearing white. The tall man had fine features and short, dark hair. Most women would probably call him handsome. He smelled . . . better than the other Whitecloaks. They had a wild scent to them, like that of a rabid animal. This leader of theirs smelled calm, and not sickly at all.

pɛɹɪn ɡlæns təwɔɹɾ ɪz kəmpænjənz.

Perrin glanced toward his companions.

"aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðɪs, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɛdʒɹə sɛd, lʊkɪŋ fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd. "ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən əv ə sɛns ə ɹɔŋɡnəs əbaʊt ðɛm."

"I do not like this, Perrin Aybara," Edarra said, looking from side to side. "These Children have a sense of wrongness about them."

"ɑɹtʃɝz kəd hɪɾ əs fɹəm ðoʊz tʃɹiz," tɑɹn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə stæn ɪn ðə dɪstəns.

"Archers could hit us from those trees," Tarn said with a grunt, nodding to a stand in the distance.

"ɡɹeɪɾi, jəɹ hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Grady, you're holding the Power?" Perrin asked.

"ʌv kɔɹs."

"Of course."

"bi ɹɛɾi, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ðən stɛp fɔɹwɝd təwɔɹd ðə smɔl ɡɹup ʌv waɪtkloʊks. ðɛɹ liɾɝ stʌɾid pɛɹɪn wɪð hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. "ɡoʊldən aɪz," ðə mæn sɛd. "soʊ ɪts tʃɹu."

"Be ready, just in case," Perrin said, then stepped forward toward the small group of Whitecloaks. Their leader studied Perrin with hands clasped behind his back. "Golden eyes," the man said. "So it is true."

"jɔɹ ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You're the Lord Captain Commander?" Perrin asked.

"aɪ æm."

"I am."

"wʌt wɪl ɪt teɪk fəɹ jə tə ɹilis ðə pipəl ə maɪn jəɹ hoʊldɪŋ?"

"What will it take for you to release the people of mine you're holding?"

"maɪ mɛn tɛl mi ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd sətʃ ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒ wʌns," ðə waɪtkloʊk liɾɝ sɛd. "æn ðət jə dɪsivd əm ən bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm."

"My men tell me they tried such an exchange once," the Whitecloak leader said. "And that you deceived them and betrayed them."

"ðeɪ hæd kɪdnæpt ɪnəsəns," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn dɪmændəd maɪ laɪf ɪn ɹɪtɝn. wɛl, aɪ tʊk maɪ pipəl bæk. doʊn fɔɹs mi tə də ðə seɪm θɪŋ hɪɹ."

"They had kidnapped innocents," Perrin said. "And demanded my life in return. Well, I took my people back. Don't force me to do the same thing here."

ðə waɪtkloʊk liɾɝ nɛɹoʊɾ ɪz aɪz. hi smɛl θɔtfəl. "aɪ wɪl də wʌɾ ɪz ɹaɪt, ɡoʊldeɪniz. ðə kɑst ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt. maɪ mɛn tɛl mi jə mɝɾɝd sɛvɹəl tʃɪlʒɹən ə fju jɪɹz bæk, ən əv nɛvɝ noʊn dʒʌstəs fəɹ ɪt. ðət jə lɛd tʃɹɑləks tə ətæk vɪlədʒəz."

The Whitecloak leader narrowed his eyes. He smelled thoughtful. "I will do what is right, Goldeneyes. The cost is irrelevant. My men tell me you murdered several Children a few years back, and have never known justice for it. That you lead Trollocs to attack villages."

"jɔɹ mɛn ɑɹ nɑt vɛɹi ɹɪlaɪəbəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹaʊl. "aɪ wɑn ə mɔɹ fɔɹməl pɑɹli, wɛɹ wi kən sɪt daʊn ən dɪskʌs. nɑt sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɹəvaɪz laɪk ðɪs."

"Your men are not very reliable," Perrin said with a growl. "I want a more formal parley, where we can sit down and discuss. Not something improvised like this."

"aɪ daʊt ðət wɪl bi niɾəd," ðə waɪtkloʊk liɾɝ sɛd. "aɪ æm nɑt hɪɹ tə bɑɹɡən. aɪ mɪɹli wɑntəd tə si jə fəɹ maɪsɛlf. jə wɪʃ jəɹ pipəl fɹid? mit maɪ ɑɹmi ɑn ðə fild ə bæɾəl. də ðɪs, ən əl ɹilis ðə kæptɪvz, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ði aʊtkʌm. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɑbviəsli nɑt soʊlʒɝz. əl lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ."

"I doubt that will be needed," the Whitecloak leader said. "I am not here to bargain. I merely wanted to see you for myself. You wish your people freed? Meet my army on the field of battle. Do this, and I will release the captives, regardless of the outcome. They are obviously not soldiers. I will let them go."

"æn ɪf aɪ ɹɛfjus?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"And if I refuse?" Perrin asked.

"ðɛn ɪɾəl nɑt boʊd . . . wɛl fəɹ ðɛɹ hɛlθ."

"Then it will not bode . . . well for their health."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ.

Perrin ground his teeth.

"jɔɹ fɔɹs wɪl feɪs aʊɝz ʌndɝ ðə laɪt," ðə waɪtkloʊk liɾɝ sɛd. "ðoʊz ɑɹ əɹ tɝmz."

"Your force will face ours under the Light," the Whitecloak leader said. "Those are our terms."

pɛɹɪn ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd. ɡɹeɪɾi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz, ən ðəɹ wɑz ən ɑbviəs kwɛstʃən ɪn ðɛm. hi kəd teɪk ðə waɪtkloʊk liɾɝ kæptɪv ɹaɪt hɪɹ, wɪð bɛɹli ə θɔt.

Perrin glanced to the side. Grady met his eyes, and there was an obvious question in them. He could take the Whitecloak leader captive right here, with barely a thought.

pɛɹɪn wɑz tɛmptəd. bʌt ðeɪ hæd kʌm ʌndɝ ðə waɪtkloʊks oʊθ ɛf seɪfti. hi wəd nɑt bɹeɪk ðə pis. ɪnstɛd, hi tɝnd, ən lɛɾ ɪz pipəl bæk təwɔɹɾ ɪz kæmp.

perrin was tempted. But they had come under the Whitecloak's oath f safety. He would not break the peace. Instead, he turned, and led his people back toward his camp.

ɡɑləd wɑtʃt eɪbɑɹə wɪðdʒɹɔ. ðoʊz ɡoʊldən aɪz wɝ ənsɛɾəlɪŋ. hi hæd dɪskaʊntɪd baɪɑɝz ɪnsɪstəns ðət ðɪs mæn wɑz nɑt mɪɹli ə dɑɹk-fɹɛnd, bʌt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. haʊɛvɝ, lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðoʊz aɪz, ɡɑləd wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɝɾən i kəd dɪsmɪs ðoʊz kleɪmz.

Galad watched Aybara withdraw. Those golden eyes were unsettling. He had discounted Byar's insistence that this man was not merely a Dark-friend, but Shadowspawn. However, looking into those eyes, Galad was no longer certain he could dismiss those claims.

tə ðə saɪd, bɔɹnhəld lɛɾ aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ. "aɪ kæn bɪliv jə wɑntəd tə də ðɪs. wʌɾ ɪf i hæd bɹɔɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ? wi kʊdn əv stɑp ðə wʌn paʊɝ."

To the side, Bornhald let out a breath. "I can't believe you wanted to do this. What if he had brought Aes Sedai? We couldn't have stopped the One Power."

"ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv hɑɹmd mi," ɡɑləd sɛd. "æn bɪsaɪdz, ɪf eɪbɑɹə hæd ði əbɪləɾi tə əsæsəneɪt mi hɪɹ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, hi cʊɾə dʌn ðə seɪm tə mi ɪn maɪ kæmp. bʌɾ ɪf hiz əz jə ən tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ seɪ, ðən i wɝiz ɡɹeɪtli əbaʊɾ ɪz ɪmədʒ. hi dɪdn lɛd tʃɹɑləks əɡɛns ðə tu ɹɪvɝz dɝɛkli. hi pɹitɛndəd tə dɪfɛn ðɛm." sətʃ ə mæn wəɾ ækt wɪð sʌɾəlti. ɡɑləd hæd bɪn seɪf.

"They would not have harmed me," Galad said. "And besides, if Aybara had the ability to assassinate me here with the One Power, he could have done the same to me in my camp. But if he is as you and Child Byar say, then he worries greatly about his image. He didn't lead Trollocs against the Two Rivers directly. He pretended to defend them." Such a man would act with subtlety. Galad had been safe.

hid wɑntəd tə si eɪbɑɹə hɪmsɛlf, ən i wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæd. ðoʊz aɪz . . . ðeɪ wɝ ɔlmoʊst ə kɑndəmneɪʃən baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. ən eɪbɑɹə hæd ɹiæktəd tə ðə mɛnʃən ə ðə mɝɾɝd waɪtkloʊks, stɪfənɪŋ. bɪɑn ðæt, ðəɹ wɑz ðə tɔk ɪz pipəl ɡeɪv ə hɪm ɪn əlaɪəns wɪð ðə ʃɔn-tʃæn ən hævɪŋ wɪð ɪm mɛn u kəd tʃænəl.

He'd wanted to see Aybara himself, and he was glad he had. Those eyes . . . they were almost a condemnation by themselves. And Aybara had reacted to the mention of the murdered Whitecloaks, stiffening. Beyond that, there was the talk his people gave of him in alliance with the Sean-chan and having with him men who could channel.

jɛs, ðɪs eɪbɑɹə wɑz ə deɪnʒɝəs mæn. ɡɑləd hæd bɪn wɝiɾ əbaʊt kəmɪɾɪŋ ɪz fɔɹsɪz tə faɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ, bʌt ðə laɪt wəd si ðɛm θɹu ɪt. bɛɾɝ tə dɪfit ðɪs eɪbɑɹə naʊ, ðən tə weɪɾ ən feɪs ɪm ət ðə læs bæɾəl. əz kwɪkli əz ðæt, hi meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən. ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən. ðeɪ wəd faɪt.

Yes, this Aybara was a dangerous man. Galad had been worried about committing his forces to fighting here, but the Light would see them through it. Better to defeat this Aybara now, than to wait and face him at the Last Battle. As quickly as that, he made his decision. The right decision. They would fight.

"kʌm," ɡɑləd sɛd, weɪvɪŋ tə hɪz mɛn. "lɛts ɡɛt bæk tə kæmp."

"Come," Galad said, waving to his men. "Let's get back to camp."


tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən


CHAPTER 11

ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd lɛɾɝ


An Unexpected Letter

ðeɪ kæn pɑsəbli θɪŋk əl saɪn ðɪs," ɪleɪn sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ðə ʃif ə peɪpɝz ɑntu ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ. "ɪts ənlaɪkli ðət ðeɪ du," daɪɛlɪn sɛd. hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ wɑz pɹɪstin, hɝ fɝm feɪs kəntʃɹoʊld, hɝ slɪm bɑɾi pɔɪzd. ðə wʊmən wɑz pɝfəkt! ɪt wɑz ənfɛɹ ðət ʃi ʃəd lʊk soʊ pɹɪstin waɪl ɪleɪn fɛlt laɪk ə saʊ, fæɾənd ʌp ən ɹaɪp fəɹ ðə slɔɾɝ.

They can't possibly think I'll sign this," Elayne said, tossing the sheaf of papers onto the floor beside her chair. "It's unlikely that they do," Dyelin said. Her golden hair was pristine, her firm face controlled, her slim body poised. The woman was perfect! It was unfair that she should look so pristine while Elayne felt like a sow, fattened up and ripe for the slaughter.

ðə hɑɹθ ɪn ɪleɪnz sɪɾɪŋ ɹum kɹækəld wɔɹmli. waɪn sæɾ ɪn ə pɪtʃɝ ɑn wʌn ə ðə wɔlz saɪdbɔɹdz, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs ʃi wɑzn əlaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ðæt. ɪf wʌn mɔɹ pɝsən tʃɹaɪd tə ɔfɝ əɹ blʌɾi ɡoʊts mɪlk . . .

The hearth in Elayne's sitting room crackled warmly. Wine sat in a pitcher on one of the wall's sideboards, but of course she wasn't allowed any of that. If one more person tried to offer her bloody goat's milk . . .

bɝdʒɪt laʊnʒd nɪɹ ðə fɑɹ wɔl, ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ, kəntʃɹæstɪŋ wɪð əɹ waɪt-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊɾ ən skaɪ-blu tʃɹaʊzɝz. ʃid pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti, ən smaɪld oʊvɝ ɪt, əmjuz baɪ ɪleɪnz ənɔɪəns. ɪleɪn kəd fil ði ɪmoʊʃən θɹu ðə bɑnd!

Birgitte lounged near the far wall, golden braid hanging over her right shoulder, contrasting with her white-collared red coat and sky-blue trousers. She'd poured herself a cup of tea, and smiled over it, amused by Elayne's annoyance. Elayne could feel the emotion through the bond!

ðeɪ wɝ ði oʊnli wʌnz ɪn ðə ɹum. ɪleɪn hæd ɹɪtaɪɹd tə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum æftɝ æksɛptɪŋ ðə pɹəpoʊzəl fɹəm ɛlɹinz mɛsənʒɝ, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðət ʃi wəd laɪk tə "kənsɪɾɝ" ði ɔfɝ ɪn pɹaɪvət.

They were the only ones in the room. Elayne had retired to the sitting room after accepting the proposal from Ellorien's messenger, explaining that she would like to "consider" the offer in private.

wɛl, ʃid kənsɪɾɝ ɪt! kənsɪɾɝ ɪt tʃɹæʃ, fəɹ ðət wɑz ɔl ɪt wɑz!

Well, she'd consider it! Consider it trash, for that was all it was!

"ðɪs ɪz ən ɪnsəlt," ʃi sɛd, swipɪŋ əɹ hæn təwɔɹd ðə peɪdʒəz.

"This is an insult," she said, sweeping her hand toward the pages.

"du jə ɪntɛn tə kip əm ɪmpɹɪzən fɝɛvɝ, ɪleɪn?" daɪɛlɪn æskt, ɹeɪzɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ.

"Do you intend to keep them imprisoned forever, Elayne?" Dyelin asked, raising an eyebrow.

"ðeɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə peɪ ə ɹænsəm, nɑɾ æftɝ wʌt ðeɪ spɛn fʌndɪŋ ðɛɹ səksɛʃən bɪd. ðət livz jə wɪð ə dɪsɪʒən."

"They can't afford to pay a ransom, not after what they spent funding their Succession bid. That leaves you with a decision."

"ðeɪ kən ɹɑt," ɪleɪn sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "ðeɪ ɹeɪzd ɑɹmiz ɡeɪns mi ən bɪsidʒ keɪɛmlɪn!"

"They can rot," Elayne said, folding her arms. "They raised armies gainst me and besieged Caemlyn!"

"jɛs," daɪɛlɪn sɛd flætli. "aɪ bɪliv aɪ wɑz ðɛɹ."

"Yes," Dyelin said flatly. "I believe I was there."

ɪleɪn kɝst sɔfli tə hɝsɛlf, ðən stʊɾ ʌp ən bɪɡæn tə peɪs. bɝdʒɪɾ aɪd hɝ; ðeɪ boʊθ nu ðət mɛlfən hæd sədʒɛstəd ðəɾ ɪleɪn əvɔɪd tæksɪŋ hɝsɛlf. ɪleɪn mɛt ðə wɔɹɾɝz aɪz stʌbɝnli, ðən kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ peɪsɪŋ. bɝn hɝ, ən bɝn ðət blʌɾi mɪdwaɪf! wɔkɪŋ wɑzn tæksɪŋ.

Elayne cursed softly to herself, then stood up and began to pace. Birgitte eyed her; they both knew that Melfane had suggested that Elayne avoid taxing herself. Elayne met the Warder's eyes stubbornly, then continued her pacing. Burn her, and burn that bloody midwife! Walking wasn't taxing.

ɛlɹin wɑz wʌn ə ðə læs voʊkəl hoʊldaʊts tə ɪleɪnz ɹul, ən wɑz ðə moʊs pɹɑbləmæɾɪk - seɪv, pɝhæps, fəɹ dʒɑɝɪd sɑɝənd. ðiz mʌnθs mɑɹk ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ə lɔŋ pɪɹiəɾ ə tɛstɪŋ fəɹ ɪleɪn.

Ellorien was one of the last vocal holdouts to Elayne's rule, and was the most problematic - save, perhaps, for Jarid Sarand. These months marked the beginning of a long period of testing for Elayne.

haʊ wəd ʃi stæn ɑn sɝɾən ɪʃuz? haʊ izəli wəd ʃi bi pʊʃt? haʊ mʌtʃ dɪd ʃi teɪk æftɝ əɹ mʌðɝ?

How would she stand on certain issues? How easily would she be pushed? How much did she take after her mother?

ðeɪ ʃəd noʊ ðət ʃi wʊdn bi izəli ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd. bʌt ði ənfɔɹtʃənət tʃɹuθ wɑz ðət ʃi stʊɾ ətɑp ə pɹikɛɹiəs pɝtʃ meɪɾ ə tikəps, stæk haɪ. itʃ ə ðoʊz kʌps wɑz ən ændɔɝən haʊs; səm hæd səpɔɹɾəd əɹ wɪlɪŋli, ʌðɝz ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. vɛɹi fju ʌv əm wɝ əz stɝɾi əz ʃi wəɾ əv laɪkt.

They should know that she wouldn't be easily intimidated. But the unfortunate truth was that she stood atop a precarious perch made of teacups, stacked high. Each of those cups was an Andoran House; some had supported her willingly, others grudgingly. Very few of them were as sturdy as she would have liked.

"ðə kæptɪv noʊbəlz ɑɹ ə ɹisɔɹs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ ʃəd bi vjuɾ əz sʌtʃ."

"The captive nobles are a resource," Elayne said. "They should be viewed as such."

daɪɛlɪn nɑɾəd. ðə noʊbəlwʊmən hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv ɡoʊɾɪŋ ɪleɪn, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ tə stʃɹɛtʃ fəɹ ði ænsɝz ðeɪ boʊθ nu ʃi niɾəd tə faɪnd. "ə ɹisɔɹs ɪz minɪŋləs ənlɛs ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɪkspɛndɪd,"

Dyelin nodded. The noblewoman had a way of goading Elayne, forcing her to stretch for the answers they both knew she needed to find. "A resource is meaningless unless eventually expended,"

daɪɛlɪn noʊɾəd. ʃi hɛld ə kʌp ʌv waɪn. blæstəd wʊmən.

Dyelin noted. She held a cup of wine. Blasted woman.

"jɛs," ɪleɪn sɛd, "bʌt tə sɛl ə ɹisɔɹs ʃɔɹt wəd bi tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ kɛɹləsnəs."

"Yes," Elayne said, "but to sell a resource short would be to establish a reputation for carelessness."

"ənlɛs jə sɛl sʌmθɪŋ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ɪts vælju plʌməts," daɪɛlɪn sɛd. "mɛni ə mɝtʃən əz bɪn kɔl fulɪʃ fəɹ tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ aɪs pɛpɝz əɾ ə dɪskaʊnt, oʊnli tə bi kɔld waɪz wən pɹaɪsəz fɔl ivən fɝðɝ."

"Unless you sell something just before its value plummets," Dyelin said. "Many a merchant has been called foolish for trading ice peppers at a discount, only to be called wise when prices fall even further."

"æn ðiz kæptɪvz? jə si ðɛɹ vælju fɔlɪŋ sun?"

"And these captives? You see their value falling soon?"

'ðɛɹ haʊsəz əv bɪn kɑmpɹəmaɪzd," daɪɛlɪn sɛd. "ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ jəɹ pəzɪʃən bɪkʌmz, ɪleɪn, ðə lɛs væljəbəl ðiz pəlɪɾəkəl kæptɪvz ɡɹoʊ. jə ʃʊdn skwɑndɝ ði ædvæntɪdʒ, bʌt niðɝ ʃəd jə lɑk ɪɾ əweɪ əntɪl noʊbɑdi kɛɹz ɛnimɔɹ."

'Their Houses have been compromised," Dyelin said. "The stronger your position becomes, Elayne, the less valuable these political captives grow. You shouldn't squander the advantage, but neither should you lock it away until nobody cares anymore."

"ju kəɾ ɛksəkjut ðɛm," bɝdʒɪt sɛd.

"You could execute them," Birgitte said.

ðeɪ boʊθ stɛɹɾ ət hɝ.

They both stared at her.

wʌt?" bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "ɪts wʌt ðeɪ dɪzɝv, ən ɪt wəɾ ɪstæblɪʃ ə hɑɹd fɪstɪd ɹɛpjəteɪʃən."

What?" Birgitte said. "It's what they deserve, and it would establish a hard fisted reputation."

ɪts nɑt ɹaɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt bi kɪl fəɹ səpɔɹɾɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛls fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn.

It's not right," Elayne said. "They should not be killed for supporting someone else for the throne.

ðəɹ kən bi noʊ tʃɹizən wɛɹ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ kwin."

There can be no treason where there is no Queen."

"soʊ əɹ soʊlʒɝz kən daɪ, bʌt ðə noʊbəlz blʌɾi wɔk əweɪ?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt. ðən ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn kəd pɹoʊtɛst. "spɛɹ ðə lɛk-tʊɹ, ɪleɪn. aɪ ʌndɝstænd. aɪ doʊn əɡɹi, bʌɾ aɪ ʌndɝstænd. ɪts ɔlweɪz bɪn ðɪs weɪ."

"So our soldiers can die, but the nobles bloody walk away?" Birgitte asked. Then she raised a hand before Elayne could protest. "Spare the lec-ture, Elayne. I understand. I don't agree, but I understand. It's always been this way."

ɪleɪn ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ peɪsɪŋ. ʃi dɪd stɑp, haʊɛvɝ, tə stɑmp ɑn ɛl-lɔɹinz pɹəpoʊzəl əz ʃi pæst ɪt. ðəɾ ɝn əɹ ən aɪ ɹoʊl fɹəm bɝdʒɪt bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɡʊd. ðə "pɹəpoʊzəl" wɑz ə lɪst ʌv ɛmpti pɹɑməsəz ðət kənkluɾəd wɪð ə dɪmæn ðəɾ ɪleɪn ɹilis ðə kæptɪvz fəɹ "ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ændɝ." ɛlɹin kleɪm ðət sɪns ðə kæptɪvz hæd noʊ fʌnz, ðə kɹaʊn ʃəd pɑɹɾən əm ən ɹilis əm tə hɛlp ɹibɪld.

Elayne returned to her pacing. She did stop, however, to stomp on El-lorien's proposal as she passed it. That earned her an eye roll from Birgitte but it felt good. The "proposal" was a list of empty promises that concluded with a demand that Elayne release the captives for "the good of Andor." Ellorien claimed that since the captives had no funds, the crown should pardon them and release them to help rebuild.

tʃɹuθ bi toʊld, ɪleɪn hæd bɪn kənsɪɾɝɪŋ duɪŋ soʊ. bʌt naʊ ɪf ʃi ɹilis ðɛm, ðə θɹi wəd si ɛlɹin əz ðɛɹ seɪvjɝ! ɛni ɡɹæɾətud ðəɾ ɪleɪn cʊɾə ɡeɪnd wəɾ ɪnstɛd bi ɡɪvən tə hɝ ɹaɪvəl. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!

Truth be told, Elayne had been considering doing so. But now if she released them, the three would see Ellorien as their savior! Any gratitude that Elayne could have gained would instead be given to her rival. Blood and bloody ashes!

"ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɑɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə æsk æftɝ ðə læn jə pɹɑməs ðɛm," daɪɛlɪn noʊɾəd.

"The Windfinders are beginning to ask after the land you promised them," Dyelin noted.

"ɔlɹɛɾi?"

"Already?"

ði oʊldɝ wʊmən nɑɾəd. "ðə ɹɪkwɛst stɪl tʃɹʌbəlz mi. waɪ də ðeɪ wɑn ə slɪvɝ ə læn laɪk ðæt?"

The older woman nodded. "The request still troubles me. Why do they want a sliver of land like that?"

"ðeɪ ɝn ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"They earned it," Elayne said.

"pɝhæps. ðoʊ ðɪs dʌz min ðət jəɹ ðə fɝs kwin ɪn faɪv dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz tə siɾ ə pɔɹʃən ʌv ændɝ - noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ smɔl - tə ə fɔɹən ɛntəɾi."

"Perhaps. Though this does mean that you're the first Queen in five generations to cede a portion of Andor - no matter how small - to a foreign entity."

ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ɑdli faʊn hɝsɛlf kɑmɝ. blæstəd mud swɪŋz! hædn mɛlfən pɹɑməs ðoʊz wəd ɡɹoʊ lɛs pɹənaʊnst əz ðə pɹɛɡnənsi pɹəɡɹɛst? jɛɾ ət taɪmz ʃi stɪl fɛlt əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz baʊnsɪŋ ɝaʊn laɪk ə bɔl ɪn ə tʃɪlʒɹənz ɡeɪm.

Elayne took a deep breath, and oddly found herself calmer. Blasted mood swings! Hadn't Melfane promised those would grow less pronounced as the pregnancy progressed? Yet at times she still felt her emotions bouncing around like a ball in a children's game.

ɪleɪn kəmpoʊz hɝsɛlf ən sæt. "aɪ kænɑɾ əlaʊ ðɪs. ðə haʊsəz ɑɹ ɔl lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɑpɝtunəɾiz tə ʃoʊldɝ ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə paʊɝ."

Elayne composed herself and sat. "I cannot allow this. The Houses are all looking for opportunities to shoulder their way into power."

"ju wəd bi duɪŋ ðə seɪm ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪs, aɪ wɔɹənt," daɪɛlɪn sɛd.

"You would be doing the same in their place, I warrant," Dyelin said.

"nɑɾ ɪf aɪ nu ðət ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ," ɪleɪn snæpt. "wi nid tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə dɝɛk ðə noʊbəlz təwɔɹd mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz. sʌmθɪŋ tə junəfaɪ ðɛm bɪhaɪn mi, əɹ ət lis kənvɪns əm ðəɾ aɪm nɑt tə bi tɔɪd wɪð."

"Not if I knew that the Last Battle was approaching," Elayne snapped. "We need to do something to direct the nobles toward more important matters. Something to unify them behind me, or at least convince them that I'm not to be toyed with."

"æn juv ə minz ʌv ətʃivɪŋ ðɪs?" daɪɛlɪn æskt.

"And you have a means of achieving this?" Dyelin asked.

"jɛs," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ istwɝd. "ɪts taɪm tə siz kɛɹhin."

"Yes," Elayne said, glancing eastward. "It's time to seize Cairhien."

bɝdʒɪt tʃoʊkt kwaɪətli ɑn əɹ ti. daɪɛlɪn mɪɹli ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "ə boʊl muv."

Birgitte choked quietly on her tea. Dyelin merely raised an eyebrow. "A bold move."

"boʊld?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt, waɪpɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn. "ɪts blʌɾi ɪnseɪn. ɪleɪn, jə bɛɹli hæv jəɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ændɝ."

"Bold?" Birgitte asked, wiping her chin. "It's bloody insane. Elayne, you barely have your fingers on Andor."

"ðæt meɪks ðə taɪmɪŋ ivən bɛɾɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "wi hæv moʊmən-bɪsaɪdz, ɪf wi muv fəɹ kɛɹhin naʊ, ɪɾəl ʃoʊ ðəɾ aɪ min tə bi mɔɹ ðən ə sɪmpɝɪŋ pʌf ʌv ə kwin."

"That makes the timing even better," Elayne said. "We have momen-Besides, if we move for Cairhien now, it will show that I mean to be more than a simpering puff of a queen."

"aɪ daʊɾ ɛniwʌn ɪkspɛks ðəɾ ə ju," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "ɪf ðeɪ du, ðeɪ oʊbəbli tʊk wʌn tu mɛni nɑks tə ðə hɛd dʊɹɪŋ ðə faɪɾɪŋ."

"I doubt anyone expects that of you," Birgitte said. "If they do, they obably took one too many knocks to the head during the fighting."

"ʃiz ɹaɪt, haʊɛvɝ ʌnkuθ ðə pɹɛzənteɪʃən," daɪɛlɪn əɡɹid. ʃi lænst ət bɝdʒɪt, ən ɪleɪn kəd fil ə stæb ə dɪslaɪk θɹu bɝdʒɪts bɑnd. laɪt! wʌt wəɾ ɪt teɪk tə meɪk ðə tu ʌv əm ɡɛɾ əlɔŋ? "noʊbɑdi daʊts jəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ əz ə kwin, ɪleɪn. ðət woʊn stɑp ði ʌðɝz fɹəm sizɪŋ wʌt paʊɝ ðeɪ kæn; ðeɪ noʊ ðəɹ ənlaɪkli tə bi eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ɪt leɪɾɝ."

"She's right, however uncouth the presentation," Dyelin agreed. She lanced at Birgitte, and Elayne could feel a stab of dislike through Birgitte's bond. Light! What would it take to make the two of them get along? "Nobody doubts your strength as a queen, Elayne. That won't stop the others from seizing what power they can; they know they're unlikely to be able to get it later."

"aɪ doʊn əv fɪftin jɪɹz tə steɪbəlaɪz maɪ ɹul, laɪk mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "lʊk, wi ɔl noʊ wʌt ɹænd kɛp seɪɪŋ əbaʊt mi teɪkɪŋ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. ə stuɝd ɹulz ðəɹ naʊ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi, ən æftɝ wʌt hæpən tə koʊləveɪɪɹ, noʊbɑdi dɛɹz dɪsəbeɪ ɹændz iɾɪkts."

"I don't have fifteen years to stabilize my rule, like Mother," Elayne said. "Look, we all know what Rand kept saying about me taking the Sun Throne. A steward rules there now, waiting for me, and after what happened to Colavaere, nobody dares disobey Rand's edicts."

"baɪ teɪkɪŋ ðət θɹoʊn," daɪɛlɪn sɛd, "ju ɹɪsk lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf jəɹ lɛɾɪŋ ælθɹ hæn ɪt tə ju."

"By taking that throne," Dyelin said, "you risk looking as if you're letting al'Thor hand it to you."

"soʊ?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæd tə teɪk ændɝ ɑn maɪ oʊn, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð mi æksɛptɪŋ ɪz ɡɪft ə kɛɹhin. hɪz il wɝ ðə wʌnz tə lɪbɝeɪɾ ɪt. wid bi duɪŋ ðə kɛɹhinɪn ə feɪvɝ baɪ pɹɪvɛntɪŋ ə mɛsi səksɛʃən. maɪ kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn ɪz stʃɹɔŋ, ət list əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz, ən ðoʊz lɔɪəl tə ɹænd wɪl fɔl bɪhaɪn mi."

"So?" Elayne said. "I had to take Andor on my own, but there is nothing wrong with me accepting his gift of Cairhien. His Aiel were the ones to liberate it. We'd be doing the Cairhienin a favor by preventing a messy Succession. My claim to the throne is strong, at least as strong as anyone else's, and those loyal to Rand will fall behind me."

"æn dʒju nɑt ɹɪsk oʊvɝɪkstɛndɪŋ jɝsɛlf?"

"And do you not risk overextending yourself?"

"pɑsəbli," ɪleɪn sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ɪts wɝθ ðə ɹɪsk. ɪn wʌn stɛp aɪ kəd bɪkʌm wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl mɑnɑɹks sɪns ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ."

"Possibly," Elayne said, "but I think it's worth the risk. In one step I could become one of the most powerful monarchs since Artur Hawkwing."

fɝðɝ ɑɹɡjəmənt wɑz kʌɾ ɔf baɪ ə pəlaɪt nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ. ɪleɪn ɡlænst ət daɪɛlɪn, ən ðə wʊmənz θɔtfəl ɪkspɹɛʃən mɛnt ʃi wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd sɛd. wɛl, ɪleɪn wəd stʃɹaɪk fəɹ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, wɪð əɹ wɪθaʊt daɪɛlɪnz əpɹuvəl. ðə wʊmən wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli jusfəl tə ɪleɪn əz ən ædvaɪzɝ - laɪt bi pɹeɪz ðət daɪɛlɪn hædnt wɑntəd ðə θɹoʊn hɝsɛlf! - bʌɾ ə kwin kəd nɑt lɛt hɝsɛlf fɔl ɪndə ðə tʃɹæp ə ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn ɛni wʌn pɝsən tu mʌtʃ.

Further argument was cut off by a polite knock at the door. Elayne glanced at Dyelin, and the woman's thoughtful expression meant she was considering what Elayne had said. Well, Elayne would strike for the Sun Throne, with or without Dyelin's approval. The woman was becoming increasingly useful to Elayne as an advisor - Light be praised that Dyelin hadn't wanted the throne herself! - but a queen could not let herself fall into the trap of relying on any one person too much.

bɝdʒɪɾ ænsɝd ðə dɔɹ, lɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə stɔɹklaɪk mæstɝ nɔɹi. hi wɑz dʒɹɛst ɪn ɹɛɾ ən waɪt, hɪz lɔŋ feɪs kɛɹəktɝɪstɪkli sɑmbɝ. hi kæɹiɾ ɪz lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ʌndɝ wʌn ɑɹm, ən ɪleɪn səpɹɛst ə ɡɹoʊn. "aɪ θɔt wi wɝ fɪnɪʃt fəɹ ðə deɪ."

Birgitte answered the door, letting in the storklike Master Norry. He was dressed in red and white, his long face characteristically somber. He carried his leather folder under one arm, and Elayne suppressed a groan. "I thought we were finished for the day."

aɪ θɔt soʊ əz wɛl, jəɹ mædʒəsti," hi sɛd. "bʌt sɛvɹəl nu mæɾɝz əv ɝɪzən. aɪ θɔt ðət ðeɪ maɪt bi . . . ʌm . . . ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ tə ju."

I thought so as well, Your Majesty," he said. "But several new matters have arisen. I thought that they might be . . . um . . . interesting to you."

'wʌt dʒju min?"

'What do you mean?"

"wɛl, jəɹ mædʒəsti," nɔɹi sɛd, "ju noʊ ðəɾ aɪm nɑt . . . pɑɹ-tɪkjəlɝli fɑn ə sɝɾən taɪps ʌv wɝk. bʌɾ ɪn laɪɾ ə ɹisən ədɪʃənz tə maɪ stæf, aɪ hæv sin ɹizən tə ɪkspæn maɪ ətɛnʃənz."

"Well, Your Majesty," Norry said, "you know that I am not . . . par-ticularly fond of certain types of work. But in light of recent additions to my staff, I have seen reason to expand my attentions."

"jɔɹ teɪkɪŋ əbaʊt hɑɹk, ɑɹən ju?" bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "haʊz ðə wɝθləs pis ʌv ɡɹaɪm duɪŋ?"

"You're taking about Hark, aren't you?" Birgitte said. "How's the worthless piece of grime doing?"

nɔɹi ɡlænst ət hɝ. "hi ɪz . . . ɝ . . . ɡɹaɪmi, aɪ ʃəd seɪ." hi lʊk bæk əɾ ɪleɪn. "bʌt hiz ɹæðɝ ədɛpt, wʌns ɡɪvən pɹɑpɝ moʊɾəveɪʃən. pliz fɝɡɪv mi ɪf aɪ hæv teɪkən lɪbɝɾiz, bʌɾ æftɝ ði ɪnkaʊntɝz ɹisənli- - ən ðə ɡɛsts tə jəɹ dʌnʒənz ðeɪ pɹəvaɪɾəd - aɪ θɔɾ ɪt waɪz."

Norry glanced at her. "He is . . . er . . . grimy, I should say." He looked back at Elayne. "But he is rather adept, once given proper motivation. Please forgive me if I have taken liberties, but after the encounters recently- - and the guests to your dungeons they provided - I thought it wise."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, mæstɝ nɔɹi?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"What are you talking about, Master Norry?" Elayne asked.

"mɪstʃɹəs bəseɪhin, jəɹ mædʒəsti," nɔɹi sɛd. "ðə fɝst ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən aɪ ɡeɪv əɹ ɡʊd mæstɝ hɑɹk wɑz tə wɑtʃ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛs pleɪs ə ɹɛzəɾəns - ə sɝɾən ɪn noʊn əz ðə ɡɹiɾɪŋ hɔl."

"Mistress Basaheen, Your Majesty," Norry said. "The first instruction I gave our good Master Hark was to watch the Aes Sedai s place of residence - a certain inn known as The Greeting Hall."

ɪleɪn sæɾ əpɹaɪt, filɪŋ ə bɝst ʌv ɪksaɪtmənt. dʌɑɹə bəseɪhin hæd ɹɪpiɾɪdli ətɛmptəd tə ɡeɪn ɑɾiəns wɪð ɪleɪn baɪ bʊliɪŋ ðə vɛɹiəs mɛmbɝz ə ðə pæləs stæf. ðeɪ ɔl nu naʊ, haʊɛvɝ, ðət ʃi wɑz nɑt tə bi ədmɪɾəd. ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ nɑt, ʃi wɑz ə ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪv ʌv ɪleɪɾə, ən ɪleɪn ɪntɛndəd tə hæv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð hɝ.

Elayne sat upright, feeling a burst of excitement. Duhara Basaheen had repeatedly attempted to gain audience with Elayne by bullying the various members of the palace staff. They all knew now, however, that she was not to be admitted. Aes Sedai or not, she was a representative of Elaida, and Elayne intended to have nothing to do with her.

"ju hæɾ əɹ wɑtʃt," ɪleɪn sɛɾ iɡɝli. "pliz tɛl mi jə dɪskʌvɝd sʌmθɪŋ aɪ kən juz tə bænɪʃ ðəɾ ɪnsʌfɝəbəl wʊmən."

"You had her watched," Elayne said eagerly. "Please tell me you discovered something I can use to banish that insufferable woman."

"ðɛn aɪm ʌndɝ noʊ kɑndəmneɪʃən?" mæstɝ nɔɹi æskt kɛɹfəli, stɪl əz dʒɹaɪ ən ʌnɪksaɪɾɪd əz ɛvɝ. hi wɑz jɛɾ ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst wən ɪt keɪm tə spaɪɪŋ.

"Then I am under no condemnation?" Master Norry asked carefully, still as dry and unexcited as ever. He was yet inexperienced when it came to spying.

"laɪt noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ ʃʊɾə ɔɹɾɝd ɪt dʌn maɪsɛlf. juv seɪv mi fɹəm ðəɾ oʊvɝsaɪt, mæstɝ nɔɹi. ɪf wʌt juv dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪz ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf nuz, aɪ maɪt dʒʌs bi laɪkli tə kɪs ju."

"Light no," Elayne said. "I should have ordered it done myself. You've saved me from that oversight, Master Norry. If what you've discovered is good enough news, I might just be likely to kiss you."

ðət pɹɑmptəɾ ə ɹiækʃən; hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn hɔɹɝ. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪleɪn læf, ən bɝdʒɪt tʃʌkəld əz wɛl. daɪɛlɪn dɪdn sim plizd. wɛl, ʃi kəd ɡoʊ sʌk ɑn ə ɡoʊts fʊt, fəɹ ɔl ɪleɪn kɛɹd.

That prompted a reaction; his eyes widened in horror. It was enough to make Elayne laugh, and Birgitte chuckled as well. Dyelin didn't seem pleased. Well, she could go suck on a goat's foot, for all Elayne cared.

"ɝ . . . wɛl," nɔɹi sɛd, "ðæt wʊdn bi nɛsəsɛɹi, jəɹ mædʒəsti. aɪ hæd θɔt ðæt, ɪf ðəɹ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi" - hi, laɪk ði ʌðɝz, hæd lɝnd nɑt tə ɹəfɝ tə fæljən ən ði ʌðɝz əz "ɛɛs sədaɪ" ɪn ɪleɪnz pɹɛzəns - "wi maɪt wɑnə kip ɡʊd wɑtʃ ɑn ɛni hu pɝpɔɹɾɪd tə bi fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"Er . . . well," Norry said, "that wouldn't be necessary, Your Majesty. I had thought that, if there were Darkfriends pretending to be Aes Sedai in the city" - he, like the others, had learned not to refer to Falion and the others as "Aes Sedai" in Elayne's presence - "we might want to keep good watch on any who purported to be from the White Tower."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd iɡɝli. maɪ, bʌt nɔɹi kəd ɹæmbəl!

Elayne nodded eagerly. My, but Norry could ramble!

"aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ mʌs dɪsəpɔɪn jəɹ mædʒəsti," nɔɹi sɛd, ɑbviəsli noʊɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz ɪksaɪtmənt, "ɪf jə ɑɹ hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ pɹuf ðət ðɪs wʊmən ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"I'm afraid I must disappoint Your Majesty," Norry said, obviously noting Elayne's excitement, "if you are hoping for proof that this woman is a Darkfriend."

"oʊ."

"Oh."

"haʊɛvɝ," nɔɹi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə slɛndɝ fɪŋɡɝ. "aɪ hæv ɹizən tə bi-liv ðət dʌɑɹə sədaɪ meɪ hæv hæɾ ə hæn ɪn ðə dɑkjəmɛn jə sim tə bi tʃɹiɾɪŋ wɪð . . . ʌm . . . ənjuʒəwəl ɹɛvɝəns." hi ɡlænst ət ðə peɪdʒəz pi, ni hæd tɔs tə ðə flɔɹ. wʌn bɔɹ ðə dɪstɪŋkt aʊtlaɪn ə hɝ ʃu.

"However," Norry said, raising a slender finger. "I have reason to be-lieve that Duhara Sedai may have had a hand in the document you seem to be treating with . . . um . . . unusual reverence." He glanced at the pages p, ne had tossed to the floor. One bore the distinct outline of her shoe.

"dʌɑɹə hæz bɪn miɾɪŋ wɪð ɛlɹin?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"Duhara has been meeting with Ellorien?" Elayne asked.

"ɪndid ʃi hæz," mæstɝ nɔɹi sɛd. "ðə vɪzəts ɑɹ ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ fɹ-ɛnt. ðeɪ ɑɹ dʌn wɪð səm mɛʒɝ ə sikɹəsi əz wɛl."

"Indeed she has," Master Norry said. "The visits are growing more fre-ent. They are done with some measure of secrecy as well."

ɪleɪn ɡlænst ət daɪɛlɪn. "waɪ dʌz dʌɑɹə wɑn maɪ ɹaɪvəlz fɹid?"

Elayne glanced at Dyelin. "Why does Duhara want my rivals freed?"

daɪɛlɪn lʊk tʃɹʌbəld. "ʃi kʊdn bi soʊ fulɪʃ əz tə əsum ʃi kən ɹeɪz ʌp ə muvmən əɡɛns ju, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli juzɪŋ ə ɡɹup ə bɹoʊkən, bæŋkɹəp lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz."

Dyelin looked troubled. "She couldn't be so foolish as to assume she can raise up a movement against you, particularly using a group of broken, bankrupt lords and ladies."

"jɔɹ mædʒəsti?" nɔɹi æskt. "ɪf aɪ meɪ ɔfɝ ə kɑmɛnt . . ."

"Your Majesty?" Norry asked. "If I may offer a comment . . ."

"ʌv kɔɹs, mæstɝ nɔɹi."

"Of course, Master Norry."

"pɝhæps ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ wɪð ðə leɪɾi ɛlɹin. wi doʊnt noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən ðeɪ kənspaɪɝɾ ɑn ðɪs pɹəpoʊzəl; ɪt sɪmpli sim laɪkli, dʒʌdʒɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɹikwənsi ən taɪmɪŋ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪz vɪzəts. bʌt ʃi meɪ nɑɾ əv ɹizən tə səpɔɹt jəɹ ɛnəmiz soʊ mʌtʃ əz ʃiz ɹizən tə bi ɪn ðə ɡʊd ɡɹeɪsɪz ə səm ə ðə sɪɾiz noʊbɪləɾi."

"Perhaps the Aes Sedai is trying to curry favor with the Lady Ellorien. We don't know for certain they conspired on this proposal; it simply seemed likely, judging from the frequency and timing of the Aes Sedai's visits. But she may not have reason to support your enemies so much as she has reason to be in the good graces of some of the city's nobility."

ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl. dʌɑɹə wɑzn laɪkli tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ɪleɪn sədʒɛstəd ðət ʃi də soʊ. tə ɡoʊ bæk wəd bi tə pɹizɛn ɪleɪɾə wɪð ɛmpti hænz ən ə hɑstəl ændɝ. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bi soʊ izəli dɪsweɪɾɪd. haʊɛvɝ, ɪf ʃi kəd ɹɪtɝn wɪð ðə lɔɪəlti ʌv səm ə ði ændɔɝən noʊbɪləɾi, ɪt wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ.

It was possible. Duhara wasn't likely to return to the White Tower, no matter how often Elayne suggested that she do so. To go back would be to present Elaida with empty hands and a hostile Andor. No Aes Sedai would be so easily dissuaded. However, if she could return with the loyalty of some of the Andoran nobility, it would be something.

"wɛn dʌɑɹə lɛft əɹ ɪn tə vɪzəɾ ɛlɹinz hoʊm," ɪleɪn sɛd, "haʊ dɪd ʃi dʒɹɛs?" ðoʊ ɛlɹin hæd bɹifli spoʊkən ə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ ɪsteɪts, ʃi hædn lɛft, pɝhæps ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt wɑzn pəlɪɾɪkəli jusfəl əz ə jɛt. ʃi ɹɪzaɪɾɪd ɪn əɹ mænʃən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ət ðə moʊmənt.

"When Duhara left her inn to visit Ellorien's home," Elayne said, "how did she dress?" Though Ellorien had briefly spoken of returning to her estates, she hadn't left, perhaps realizing that it wasn't politically useful as of yet. She resided in her mansion in Caemlyn at the moment.

She didn't have the coin to pay them now, but neither did she want to lose them. So instead, she had ordered Master Norry and Captain Guybon to give all of the mercenary bands the same instructions. Min sat on a window ledge in the Stone of Tear, enjoying the warmth. The afternoon breeze was refreshing, laden though it was with humidity and the scents of the city below. The Tairens had been calling the weather "chilly," which made Min smile. How would these folk respond to a good Andoran winter, with snow piled up at the sides of buildings and icicles hanging from the eaves?

Nynaeve cut off. She walked over to the corner table and poured herself a cup of chilled Tremalking black. Chilled tea. That seemed so odd. Tea was meant to be warming during cold days.

mɪn tɝn əɹ aɪz nɔɹθwɝɾ əɡɛn, ɪndə ðə dɪstənt, klaʊd-smʌðɝd heɪz. əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd dətɝmən θɹu ðə bɑnd, ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ dɝɛkli ət hɪm. wɑz i ɪn ændɝ, pɝhæps? əɹ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz? ʃid bɪn tɛmptəd tə juz ðə bɑn tə sik ɪm aʊɾ ət fɝst, wən hid fɛl ðəɾ ɑfəl æŋɡwɪʃ. peɪn dipɝ ðən ðə wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd. æɡəni, æŋɡɝ ən dɪspɛɹ. ɪn ðoʊz moʊməns, ɹænd hæd simd mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən i ɛvɝ hæd bɪfɔɹ. nɑɾ ivən ðət naɪt - wən hid nɛlt əbʌv hɝ, stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ əɹ wɪð wʌn hænd - hæɾ i bɪn əz fɹaɪɾənɪŋ.

Min turned her eyes northward again, into the distant, cloud-smothered haze. As far as she could determine through the bond, she was looking directly at him. Was he in Andor, perhaps? Or in the Borderlands? She'd been tempted to use the bond to seek him out at first, when he'd felt that awful anguish. Pain deeper than the wounds in his side. Agony, anger and despair. In those moments, Rand had seemed more dangerous than he ever had before. Not even that night - when he'd knelt above her, strangling her with one hand - had he been as frightening.

ən ðən . . .

And then . . .

ʃi smaɪld. ən ðən hæd kʌm ðə wɔɹmθ. ɪt ɹeɪɾieɪtəd fɹəm ðə bɑn laɪk ðə kʌmfɝɾ ʌv ə wɪntɝ hɑɹθ. sʌmθɪŋ wʌndɝfəl wɑz hæpənɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ ʃid bɪn əweɪɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ ɪt.

She smiled. And then had come the warmth. It radiated from the bond like the comfort of a winter hearth. Something wonderful was happening, something she'd been awaiting without knowing it.

"ɪt wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛd.

Min took a deep breath. Nynaeve had been goading her into arguments lately; she certainly had good reason to be tense. Her husband was riding toward his death. The Dragon Reborn - a man she saw as her charge, still - was wandering alone, and there was nothing Nynaeve could do. And if there was one thing Nynaeve hated, it was being powerless.

"nɪneɪiv," mɪn sɛd. "ɪf ðɪs læsts mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, əl lɛd jə tə hɪm. aɪ pɹɑməs."

mɪn stɑɹɾəd tə ɹɪplaɪ, bʌt moʊʃən dʒɹu hɝ ətɛnʃən. tu meɪɾənz -  sʊɹiəl ən lɹiən - ɡɑɹɾəd ði oʊpən dɔɹweɪ tə ðə hɔlweɪ; ðeɪd tɝn tə wɑtʃ sʌmwʌn əpɹoʊtʃ. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz meɪɾənz ɝaʊn mɪn, ðiz deɪz.

Sarene Nemdahl entered the small room a moment later. Min's quarters in the Stone were not expansive - she rarely used them, instead staying with Rand. Her sitting room had a thick blue-and- white rug and a small cherry desk, but nothing else.

And I'm telling you that I felt nothing," Corele said. She smiled, tapping the side of her nose. "I don't know how she got out. Unless you think she somehow invented flying - which I daresay wouldn't be outside reason, considering some of what has occurred lately."

ful wʊmən, kædzueɪn θɔt, lɛvəlɪŋ ə flæt stɛɹ ət kɔɹəl. ðə wʊmənz flɪpənsi wɑz pɹɛfɝəbəl tə ðə sɛlf-ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə səm ʌðɝ ɛɛs æədaɪ, bʌt tədeɪ kædzueɪn hædn ðə peɪʃəns fəɹ ɪt.

Fool woman, Cadsuane thought, leveling a flat stare at Corele. The woman's flippancy was preferable to the self-importance of some other Aes aedai, but today Cadsuane hadn't the patience for it.

The Yellow shrugged, still smiling, but said nothing further. Cadsuane Placed hands on hips, surveying the small chamber. Room for a trunk to hold clothing, a cot for sleeping and a desk. Cadsuane would have expected Aes Sedai to demand more, even in Tear. Of course, Alanna didn't often rveal her intimate connection to the Dragon. Most didn't know of it.

tu ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ - ɹæfɛlə sɪndəl ən bɛɹə hɑɹkɪn - stʊɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. bɛɹə sɛd ʃid fɛlt ɑlɑnə tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ dɪmændɪŋ sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kɹieɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ.

Two other Aes Sedai - Rafela Cindal and Bera Harkin - stood at the side of the room. Bera said she'd felt Alanna channeling, but nothing demanding Certainly not enough to create a gateway.

bɝn ðət wʊmən! kædzueɪn hæd θɔɾ ɑlɑnə wɛl ɪn hænd, dɪspaɪt ɹisən stʌbɝnnəs. ʃiɾ ɑbviəsli slɪpt aʊɾ ɪntɛnʃənəli. ðə kloʊðɪŋ fɹəm ðə tʃɹʌŋk wɑz ɡɔn ən ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk wɑz moʊsli bɛɹ. oʊnli ən ɛmpti ɪŋk bɑɾəl ɹɪmeɪnd.

Burn that woman! Cadsuane had thought Alanna well in hand, despite recent stubbornness. She'd obviously slipped out intentionally. The clothing from the trunk was gone and the writing desk was mostly bare. Only an empty ink bottle remained.

well, I did often hear weeping in her room."

"Phaw," Cadsuane said. "The girl isn't 'only one person.' She's a tool. An important one." She reached over to the desk, holding up a sheet of paper that they'd found in the room. It had been folded with a blood-red seal of wax on one side. "Do you recognize this?"

nɪneɪiv fɹaʊnd. "noʊ. ʃəɾ aɪ?"

laɪɪŋ əɹ tʃɹuθfəl? kædzueɪn heɪɾəd nɑt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃɹʌs ðə wɝdz ə sʌmwʌn u kɔl hɝsɛlf ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə hæd nɛvɝ hɛl ði oʊθ ɹɑd.

Lying or truthful? Cadsuane hated not being able to trust the words of someone who called herself an Aes Sedai. But Nynaeve al'Meara had never held the Oath Rod.

ðoʊz aɪz lʊk dʒɛnjəwənli kənfjuzd. nɪneɪiv ʃəd bi tʃɹʌstwɝði; ʃi pɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɑn əɹ ɑnəsti. ənlɛs ðət wɑz ə fɹʌnt. ənlɛs ʃi wɑz blæk.

Those eyes looked genuinely confused. Nynaeve should be trustworthy; she prided herself on her honesty. Unless that was a front. Unless she was Black.

Careful, she thought. You'll end up as distrustful as the boy is. Nynaeve hadn't given Alanna the note, which eliminated her last good theory on its origin.

"So, what is it, Cadsuane Sedai?" Nynaeve demanded. At least she used the honorific; Cadsuane nearly chided the girl for her tone. But, truth be told, she felt as frustrated as Nynaeve did. There were times when such emotions were justified. Facing the end of the world with the Dragon Reborn completely out of control was one of them.

"I'm not sure," Cadsuane said. "The letter was opened in haste - the paper was torn. It was dropped on the floor, and the note inside taken, along with clothing and emergency items."

nɪneɪiv snɪft. "ʃiz bɪn noʊ mɔɹ hɛlpfəl ðən ju, mɪn."

əz pɝsweɪsɪv əz jə kən bi, nɪneɪiv," kædzueɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ðə ʃædoʊ hæz minz tə meɪk pipəl mɔɹ fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ."

As persuasive as you can be, Nynaeve," Cadsuane said dryly, "the Shadow has means to make people more forthcoming."
