Nynaeve blushed furiously, then began muttering under her breath. Al- anna could point the way to the Dragon Reborn. If agents of the Dark One had taken her, there would be no hiding Rand from them. Their traps had been deadly enough when they'd needed to coax and lure him into them.

"wiv bɪn fulz," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðɛɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd meɪɾənz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ hɝ."

"We've been fools," Nynaeve said. "There should have been a hundred Maidens guarding her."

"ðə fɔɹseɪkən əv noʊn wɛɹ tə faɪn ɪm bɪfɔɹ," kædzueɪn sɛd, ðoʊ ɪnwɝdli ʃi əɡɹid. ʃi ʃʊɾə sin ɑlɑnə bɛɾɝ wɑtʃt. "æn hiz sɝvaɪvd. ðɪs ɪz sɪmpli wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ tə bi əwɛɹ ʌv." ʃi saɪd. "kæn sʌmwʌn bɹɪŋ əs səm ti?"

"The Forsaken have known where to find him before," Cadsuane said, though inwardly she agreed. She should have seen Alanna better watched. "And he has survived. This is simply one more thing to be aware of." She sighed. "Can someone bring us some tea?"

bɛɹə wɑz æktʃəli  ðə wʌn u wɛn tə fɛtʃ ɪt, ðoʊ kædzueɪn hædn teɪkən ɛni kɛɹ tə kʌltəveɪɾ ɪnfluəns wɪð ðə wʊmən. wɛl, ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən wɑz wɝθ sʌmθɪŋ, ɪɾ əpɪɹd.

Bera was actually the one who went to fetch it, though Cadsuane hadn't taken any care to cultivate influence with the woman. Well, a reputation was worth something, it appeared.

bɛɹə ɹɪtɝnd ʃɔɹtli; kædzueɪn hæd stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl tə θɪŋk. ʃi æksɛptɪd ðə kʌp ən bɹeɪs hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðə tiz bɪɾɝ teɪst -  ʃiɾ æsk fəɹ ɪt pɑɹʃəli kəz ʃi niɾəd ə moʊmən tə θɪŋk, ən ən ɛmpti-hændəd wʊmən ɔfən lʊk nɝvəs.

Bera returned shortly; Cadsuane had stepped out into the hall to think. She accepted the cup and braced herself for the tea's bitter taste -  she'd asked for it partially because she needed a moment to think, and an empty-handed woman often looked nervous.

ʃi ɹeɪz ðə kʌp tə hɝ lɪps. wʌt nɛkst? æsk ðə dɪfɛndɝz ət ðə ɡeɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn? læs naɪt, ɑlɑnə - æftɝ biɪŋ pɹɑɾɪd - hæd kənfɝm ðəɾ ælθɹ wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs. ʌp nɔɹθ, ændɝ pɝhæps. fəɹ θɹi deɪz. wʌt wɑz ðə ful bɔɪ -  kædzueɪn fɹoʊz. ðə ti teɪstəd ɡʊd.

She raised the cup to her lips. What next? Ask the Defenders at the gate of the Stone? Last night, Alanna - after being prodded - had confirmed that al'Thor was still in the same place. Up north, Andor perhaps. For three days. What was the fool boy -  Cadsuane froze. The tea tasted good.

ɪt wɑz wʌndɝfəl, əz ə mæɾɝ ə fækt. pɝfəkli swiɾənd wɪð hʌni. feɪn bɪɾɝnəs ən ə ɹɪlæksɪŋ fleɪvɝ. ɪt hæd bɪn wiks, pɝhæps mʌnθs, sɪns kædzueɪn hæd teɪstəd ti ðət wɑzn spɔɪld.

It was wonderful, as a matter of fact. Perfectly sweetened with honey. Faint bitterness and a relaxing flavor. It had been weeks, perhaps months, since Cadsuane had tasted tea that wasn't spoiled.

mɪn ɡæspt, tɝnɪŋ ʃɑɹpli təwɔɹd ðə nɔɹðɝn kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə sɪɾi. ðə tu meɪɾənz ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ wɝ ɡɔn ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, dæʃɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. kædzueɪnz səspɪʃənz wɝ kənfɝmd; ðɛɹ kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ ə mɪn hæd bɪn lɛs əbaʊt pɹətɛktɪŋ əɹ ən mɔɹ əbaʊt wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ saɪnz ʌv...

Min gasped, turning sharply toward the northern quarter of the city. The two Maidens in the doorway were gone in a heartbeat, dashing down the hallway. Cadsuane's suspicions were confirmed; their careful watch of Min had been less about protecting her and more about watching for signs of...

"hiz hɪɹ," mɪn sɛd sɔfli.

"He's here," Min said softly.


tʃæptɝ θɝtin


CHAPTER 13

fəɹ wʌɾ əz bɪn ɹɔt


For What Has Been Wrought

mɪn bɝs fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl ɡeɪɾ ɑn ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn ən dæʃt əkɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. wʌt sim laɪk ən ɪntaɪɝ klænz wɝθ ʌv il flʌɾəd aʊt bɪhaɪn hɝ, bɹeɪkɪŋ ɝaʊn mɪn laɪk dɪɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ ɝaʊn ən oʊk. ðeɪ wiv bɪtwin stɑɹɾəld dɪfɛndɝz ən ɡɹumz, muvɪŋ wɪð ɡɹeɪs ən spid təwɔɹd ðə wɔl.

Min burst from the Dragonwall Gate on the eastern side of the Stone and dashed across the courtyard. What seemed like an entire clan's worth of Aiel flooded out behind her, breaking around Min like deer breaking around an oak. They weaved between startled Defenders and grooms, moving with grace and speed toward the wall.

ɪt wɑz ɡɔlɪŋ haʊ izəli ðeɪ aʊtpeɪst əɹ - jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ʃid pɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɑn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə biɾ ɛni bɔɪ ʃi nu ɪn ən ɑnəs fʊtʃɹeɪs. naʊ . . . wɛl, tu mɛni mʌnθs spɛn pɪkɪŋ θɹu bʊks, pɝhæps.

It was galling how easily they outpaced her - years ago, she'd prided herself on being able to beat any boy she knew in an honest footrace. Now . . . well, too many months spent picking through books, perhaps.

ʃi stɪl aʊtpeɪs ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu wɝ bɹaɪɾəld baɪ ðɛɹ nid tə meɪnteɪn pɹɑpɝ dɪkɔɹəm.

She still outpaced the Aes Sedai, who were bridled by their need to maintain proper decorum.

mɪn hæd lɔŋ əɡoʊ tɔst əsaɪɾ ɔl sɛns ə dɪkɔɹəm fəɹ əɹ taʊɝɪŋ ʃifɝɾɝ. ən soʊ ʃi ɹæn, θæŋkfəl fəɹ əɹ bɹitʃɪz ən buts, meɪkɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡeɪt.

Min had long ago tossed aside all sense of decorum for her towering sheepherder. And so she ran, thankful for her breeches and boots, making for the gate.

ən ðəɹ i wɑz. ʃi pʊld ʌp ʃɑɹpli, lʊkɪŋ θɹu ən oʊpən kɑləm ʌv il ɪn keɪɾɪnsɝ təwɔɹd ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf, stændɪŋ ən spikɪŋ wɪð tu dɪfɛndɝz u wɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɔl ɡɑɹd.

And there he was. She pulled up sharply, looking through an open column of Aiel in cadin'sor toward the man himself, standing and speaking with two Defenders who were part of the wall guard.

hi ɡlænst əɾ əɹ əz ʃi ɡɹu kloʊs; hi kəd fil əɹ kʌmɪŋ, əz ʃi fɛl hɪm.

He glanced at her as she grew close; he could feel her coming, as she felt him.

ɹænd hæd faʊn ən oʊld, lɔŋ bɹaʊn kloʊk sʌmwɛɹ. ɪt hæd slivz laɪk ə koʊt, ðoʊ ɪt fɛl lus fɹəm ðə ʃoʊldɝz. ʌndɝniθ ɪt, hi hæɾ ɑn ə ʃɝɾ ən faɪn blæk tʃɹaʊzɝz.

Rand had found an old, long brown cloak somewhere. It had sleeves like a coat, though it fell loose from the shoulders. Underneath it, he had on a shirt and fine black trousers.

naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz kloʊz, ðə wɔɹmθ θɹu ðə bɑn simd oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ. kʊdn ði ʌðɝz si ɪt? ɪt meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə ɹeɪz əɹ ɑɹm ən ʃeɪɾ əɹ aɪz, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə æktʃəli  si.

Now that he was close, the warmth through the bond seemed overwhelming. Couldn't the others see it? It made her want to raise her arm and shade her eyes, though there was nothing to actually see.

ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə bɑnd. ɪksɛpt . . . ði ɛɹ dɪd sim tə dɪstɔɹɾ ɝaʊn hɪm. wɑz ðəɾ ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə sʌnlaɪt? nu vjuɪŋz spʌn ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd. ʃi nɔɹməli ɪɡnɔɹd ðoʊz, bʌt ʃi kʊdn də soʊ naʊ. ən oʊpən kævɝn, ɡeɪpɪŋ laɪk ə maʊθ. blʌdsteɪn ɹɑks. tu dɛd mɛn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɹæŋks ən ɹæŋks ə tʃɹɑləks, ə paɪp wɪð smoʊk kɝlɪŋ fɹəm ɪt.

It was just the bond. Except . . . the air did seem to distort around him. Was that a trick of the sunlight? New viewings spun around his head. She normally ignored those, but she couldn't do so now. An open cavern, gaping like a mouth. Bloodstained rocks. Two dead men on the ground, surrounded by ranks and ranks of Trollocs, a pipe with smoke curling from it.

ɹænd mɛɾ əɹ ɡeɪz, ən - dɪspaɪt ðə bɑnd - ʃi wɑz əmeɪzd ət wʌt ʃi sɔ ɪn hɪm. ðoʊz ɡɹeɪ dʒɛmstoʊn aɪz ə hɪz wɝ dipɝ. ðəɹ wɝ feɪn ɹɪŋkəlz ɝaʊn ðɛm. hæd ðoʊz bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ? ʃʊɹli hi wɑz tu jʌŋ fəɹ ðæt.

Rand met her gaze, and - despite the bond - she was amazed at what she saw in him. Those gray gemstone eyes of his were deeper. There were faint wrinkles around them. Had those been there before? Surely he was too young for that.

ðoʊz aɪz dɪd nɑt lʊk jʌŋ. mɪn fɛlt ə moʊmən ə pænɪk əz ɪz aɪz hɛl hɝz. wɑz ðɪs ðə seɪm mæn? hæd ðə ɹænd ʃi lʌv bɪn stoʊlən əweɪ, ɹipleɪst wɪð ən eɪntʃən fɔɹs ʌv ə mæn ʃi kəd nɛvɝ noʊ əɹ ʌndɝstænd? hæd ʃi lɔst ɪm æftɝ ɔl?

Those eyes did not look young. Min felt a moment of panic as his eyes held hers. Was this the same man? Had the Rand she loved been stolen away, replaced with an ancient force of a man she could never know or understand? Had she lost him after all?

ən ðən i smaɪld, ən ði aɪz - dip ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm -  wɝ hɪz. ðət smaɪl wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʃid bɪn weɪɾɪŋ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm tə si əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz naʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt ðən ðə wʌn hid ʃoʊn əɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ɝli deɪz təɡɛðɝ, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl vʌlnɝəbəl. ɪt lɛɾ əɹ si ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ðəɾ ʌðɝz wɝ nɛvɝ əlaʊd.

And then he smiled, and the eyes - deep though they had become -  were his. That smile was something she'd been waiting a very long time to see again. It was now much more confident than the one he'd shown her during their early days together, yet it was still vulnerable. It let her see a part of him that others were never allowed.

ðət pɑɹt wɑz ðə juθ, sʌmhaʊ ɪnəsən stɪl. ʃi ɹæn ʌp tə hɪm ən sizd ɪm ɪn ən ɛmbɹeɪs.

That part was the youth, somehow innocent still. She ran up to him and seized him in an embrace.

"ju wʊl-hɛɾəd ful! θɹi deɪz? wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ fəɹ θɹi deɪz}"

"You wool-headed fool! Three days? What have you been doing for three days}"

"ɪɡzɪstɪŋ, mɪn," hi sɛd, ɹæpɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ.

"Existing, Min," he said, wrapping his arms around her.

"aɪ wɑzn əwɛɹ ðət wɑz sətʃ ə dɪfəkəl tæsk."

"I wasn't aware that was such a difficult task."

"ɪɾ əz bɪn fəɹ mi ət taɪmz." hi fɛl saɪlənt, ən ʃi wɑz kɑntɛn tə hoʊl hɪm. jɛs, ðɪs wɑz ðə seɪm mæn. tʃeɪnʒd - ən fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ - bʌt stɪl ɹænd. ʃi klʌŋ tə hɪm. ʃi dɪdn kɛɹ ðət pipəl wɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ðɛm. lɛɾ əm wɑtʃ.

"It has been for me at times." He fell silent, and she was content to hold him. Yes, this was the same man. Changed - and for the better - but still Rand. She clung to him. She didn't care that people were gathering, more and more of them. Let them watch.

faɪnəli ʃi ɛksheɪld, ɹɪlʌktənli pʊlɪŋ bæk. "ɹænd, ɑlɑnə ɪz ɡɔn. ʃi vænɪʃt ɝliɝ tədeɪ."

Finally she exhaled, reluctantly pulling back. "Rand, Alanna is gone. She vanished earlier today."

"jɛs. aɪ fɛlt əɹ ɡoʊ. nɔɹθwɝd sʌmwɛɹ. ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, pɝhæps ɝæfəl."

"Yes. I felt her go. Northward somewhere. The Borderlands, perhaps Arafel."

"ʃi kəd bi juzd əɡɛns ju, tə faɪnd wɛɹ jə ɑɹ." hi smaɪld. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɡʊd tə si ðəɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs əɡɛn! "ðə ʃædoʊ dʌz nɑt niɾ əɹ tə faɪn mi, mɪn, nɔɹ wɪl ɪɾ ɛvɝ əɡɛn. ɔl ɪts aɪz ɑɹ fɪks dɝɛkli əpɑn mi, ən wɪl bi əntɪl aɪ blaɪn ðɛm."

"She could be used against you, to find where you are." He smiled. Light, but it felt good to see that expression on his face again! "The Shadow does not need her to find me, Min, nor will it ever again. All its eyes are fixed directly upon me, and will be until I blind them."

"wʌt? bʌt ɹænd - "

"What? But Rand - "

'ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt, mɪn. ðə taɪm wən ɪt kəd saɪləns mi kwaɪətli - ən ðɛɹfɔɹ wɪn - hæz pæst.

'It's all right, Min. The time when it could silence me quietly - and therefore win - has passed.

ðə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən ɪz əʃʊɹɾ ən ðə skɹim ðət bɪɡɪnz ði ævəlæntʃ əz bɪn saʊndəd."

The confrontation is assured and the scream that begins the avalanche has been sounded."

hi simd əfaɪɹ wɪð laɪf. ðə θɹɪl ʌv ɪt wɑz ɪntɑksɪkeɪɾɪŋ. hi lɛft ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ - ði ɑɹm ðəɾ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə stʌmp - əz i tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd ði il. "aɪ hæv toʊ." ðoʊ ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd bɪhaɪn əm wɑz ɪn keɪɑs, ði il stʊd kwaɪətli.

He seemed afire with life. The thrill of it was intoxicating. He left an arm around her - the arm that ended in a stump - as he turned to regard the Aiel. "I have toh." Though the courtyard behind them was in chaos, the Aiel stood quietly.

ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðɪs, mɪn θɔt. ði il wɝn hɑstəl, ɪɡzækli bʌt ðeɪ dɪdnt ʃɛɹ ði ɪksaɪtmən ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz. ðə tɛɹənz θɔt ɹænd hæd ɹɪtɝn tə liɾ əm tə ðə læs bæɾəl.

They were ready for this, Min thought. The Aiel weren't hostile, exactly but they didn't share the excitement of the Defenders. The Tairens thought Rand had returned to lead them to the Last Battle.

"ɪn ðə weɪst," ɹəɑɹk sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, "ðɛɹ ɪz ən ænəməl. ðə miɡɝlɪŋ. ɪt lʊks mʌtʃ laɪk ə ɹæt, bʌɾ ɪts fɑɹ mɔɹ stupəd. ɪf jə pleɪs ɪt nɪɹ ɡɹeɪn, ɪɾəl ɡoʊ stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹɾ ɪt, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə deɪnʒɝ. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni taɪmz ɪt fɔlz ɪn ə tʃɹɛntʃ bɪtwin ɪtsɛlf ən ðə fuɾ ɪɾəl ɹɪpit ðə seɪm ækʃən ɪf jə muv ɪt bæk tə ðə stɑɹt. il tʃɪlʒɹən əmjuz ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð ðə ɡeɪm." hi stʌɾid ɹænd. "aɪ hæd nɑt θɔt jə wəd bi ə miɡɝlɪŋ, ɹænd ælθɹ."

"In the Waste," Rhuarc said, stepping forward, "there is an animal. The meegerling. It looks much like a rat, but it is far more stupid. If you place it near grain, it will go straight toward it, regardless of the danger. No matter how many times it falls in a trench between itself and the food it will repeat the same action if you move it back to the start. Aiel children amuse themselves with the game." He studied Rand. "I had not thought you would be a meegerling, Rand al'Thor."

"aɪ pɹɑməs əl nɛvɝ liv jə əɡɛn," ɹænd sɛd. "nɑɾ ə maɪ oʊn tʃɔɪs, ən nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɪnfɔɹmɪŋ ən - ɪf ðeɪ kənsɛnt - bɹɪŋɪŋ meɪɾənz əz ə ɡɑɹd."

"I promise I will never leave you again," Rand said. "Not of my own choice, and not without informing and - if they consent - bringing Maidens as a guard."

ði il dɪd nɑt bʌdʒ. "ðɪs wɪl pɹɪvɛn jə fɹəm ɝnɪŋ mɔɹ toʊ" ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "ɪt wɪl nɑt tʃeɪnʒ wʌɾ əz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ. ən pɹɑməsəz əv bɪn meɪd bɪfɔɹ."

The Aiel did not budge. "This will prevent you from earning more toh" Rhuarc said. "It will not change what has gone before. And promises have been made before."

"ðɪs ɪz tʃɹu," ɹænd sɛd, miɾɪŋ ɹəɑɹks aɪz. "aɪ wɪl mit maɪ toʊ, ðɛn."

"This is true," Rand said, meeting Rhuarc's eyes. "I will meet my toh, then."

sʌmθɪŋ pæs bɪtwin ðɛm, sʌmθɪŋ mɪn dɪdn ʌndɝstænd, ən ði il pɑɹɾəd, lʊkɪŋ mɔɹ ɹɪlækst. twɛnti meɪɾənz keɪm fɔɹwɝd tə ækt əz ə ɡɑɹɾ ɝaʊn ɹænd. ɹəɑɹk ɹitʃɹiɾəd wɪð ði ʌðɝz, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ə smɔl ɡɹup ʌv waɪz wʌnz u wɑtʃt fɹəm ðə pɝɪfɝi.

Something passed between them, something Min didn't understand, and the Aiel parted, looking more relaxed. Twenty Maidens came forward to act as a guard around Rand. Rhuarc retreated with the others, joining a small group of Wise Ones who watched from the periphery.

"ɹænd?" mɪn sɛd.

"Rand?" Min said.

The gathered nobles looked disheveled, apparently summoned from naps or meals, although they wore an assortment of fine silks and ruffles. They looked oddly out of place in the Stone's courtyard, where everyone else had a purpose.

/ ʃʊdn bi soʊ hɑɹʃ ɑn ðɛm, mɪn θɔt, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi hæd wɑtʃt ðɛɹ plɑɾɪŋ ən pændɝɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪt ɹænd. bɪsaɪdz, ʃid nɛvɝ bɪn fɑn ə ðoʊz u θɔt ðɛmsɛlvz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls.

/ shouldn't be so harsh on them, Min thought, folding her arms. But then, she had watched their plotting and pandering frustrate Rand. Besides, she'd never been fond of those who thought themselves more important than everyone else.

"fɔɹm ə laɪn," ɹænd sɛd, wɔkɪŋ ʌp tə ðɛm.

"Form a line," Rand said, walking up to them.

ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz lʊkt ət hɪm, kənfjuzd.

The High Lords and Ladies looked at him, confused.

ə laɪn" ɹænd sɛd, vɔɪs laʊɾ ən fɝm. "naʊ."

A line" Rand said, voice loud and firm. "Now."

ðeɪ dɪd soʊ, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð heɪst. ɹænd bɪɡæn tə wɔk daʊn ðə ɹoʊ, stɑɹɾɪŋ wɪð dɑɹlɪn, lʊkɪŋ itʃ mæn əɹ wʊmən ɪn ði aɪ. ɹændz ɪmoʊʃənz wɝ . . . kjʊɹiəs. pɝhæps ə tʌtʃ æŋɡɹi. wʌt wɑz i duɪŋ?

They did so, arranging themselves with haste. Rand began to walk down the row, starting with Darlin, looking each man or woman in the eye. Rand's emotions were . . . curious. Perhaps a touch angry. What was he doing?

ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd ɡɹu stɪl. ɹænd kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə laɪn, lʊkɪŋ əɾ itʃ ə ðə noʊbəlz ɪn tɝn, nɑt spikɪŋ. mɪn ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd. nɪɹ ði ɛn ə ðə laɪn, wɪɹɑmɑn kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ ət ɹænd, ðən lʊkɪŋ əweɪ. ðə tɔl mæn hæd θɪnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ, hɪz bɪɹɾ ɔɪl tə ə pɔɪnt.

The courtyard grew still. Rand continued down the line, looking at each of the nobles in turn, not speaking. Min glanced to the side. Near the end of the line, Weiramon kept glancing at Rand, then looking away. The tall man had thinning gray hair, his beard oiled to a point.

ɹænd ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹitʃt hɪm. "mit maɪ aɪz, wɪɹɑmɑn," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli.

Rand eventually reached him. "Meet my eyes, Weiramon," Rand said softly.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ʃʊɹli aɪm nɑt wɝði tə - "

"My Lord Dragon, surely I am not worthy to - "

"du ɪt."

"Do it."

wɪɹɑmɑn dɪd soʊ wɪð ən ɑd dɪfəkəlti. hi lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑz ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ, hɪz aɪz wɔɾɝɪŋ.

Weiramon did so with an odd difficulty. He looked as if he was gritting his teeth, his eyes watering.

"soʊ ɪts ju," ɹænd sɛd. mɪn kəd fil ɪz dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. ɹænd lʊk tə ðə saɪd, tə wɛɹ ænɑiɛlə stʊd læst ɪn laɪn. ðə pɹɪɾi wʊmən hæd pʊld əweɪ fɹəm ɹænd, hɝ hɛd tɝnd. "boʊθ ə ju."

"So it is you," Rand said. Min could feel his disappointment. Rand looked to the side, to where Anaiyella stood last in line. The pretty woman had pulled away from Rand, her head turned. "Both of you."

"maɪ lɔɹd - " wɪɹɑmɑn bɪɡæn.

"My Lord - " Weiramon began.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə dɪlɪvɝ ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ mi," ɹænd sɛd. "tə ði ʌðɝz ə jəɹ . . . əsoʊsieɪʃən. tɛl əm ðət ðeɪ kænɑt haɪɾ əmʌŋ maɪ əlaɪz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ."

"I want you to deliver a message for me," Rand said. "To the others of your . . . association. Tell them that they cannot hide among my allies any longer."

wɪɹɑmɑn tʃɹaɪd tə blʌstɝ, bʌt ɹænd tʊk ə stɛp kloʊsɝ. wɪɹɑmɑnz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən ænɑiɛlə kɹaɪɾ aʊt, ʃeɪɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs.

Weiramon tried to bluster, but Rand took a step closer. Weiramon's eyes opened wide, and Anaiyella cried out, shading her face.

"tɛl ðɛm," ɹænd kəntɪnjud, vɔɪs sɑf bʌt dɪmændɪŋ, "ðæɾ aɪm noʊ lɔŋɡɝ blaɪnd."

"Tell them," Rand continued, voice soft but demanding, "that I am no longer blind."

"waɪ . . ." ænɑiɛlə sɛd. "waɪ ɑɹ jə lɛɾɪŋ əs ɡoʊ?"

"Why . . ." Anaiyella said. "Why are you letting us go?"

"bɪkɔz tədeɪ ɪz ə deɪ ʌv ɹiunjən," ɹænd sɛd. "nɑɾ ə deɪ ʌv dɛθ. ɡoʊ."

"Because today is a day of reunion," Rand said. "Not a day of death. Go."

ðə tu stʌmbəld əweɪ, lʊkɪŋ dʒɹeɪnd. ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɑtʃt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz ən kənfjuʒən. ði il, haʊɛvɝ, bɪɡæn tə bit ðɛɹ spɪɹz əɡɛns ðɛɹ ʃilz. ænɑiɛlə ən wɪɹɑmɑn sim tə kip tə ðə ʃædoʊz ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ dʌkt ɪndə ðə stoʊn.

The two stumbled away, looking drained. The others in the courtyard watched with surprise and confusion. The Aiel, however, began to beat their spears against their shields. Anaiyella and Weiramon seemed to keep to the shadows of the courtyard as they ducked into the Stone.

"li," ɹænd sɛd. "teɪk tu ʌðɝz. wɑtʃ ðɛm."

"Leeh," Rand said. "Take two others. Watch them."

θɹi meɪɾənz splɪt fɹəm ðoʊz wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ɹænd, dɑɹɾɪŋ æftɝ ðə tu fɔɹmɝ noʊbəlz. mɪn stɛpt ʌp tə ɹænd, teɪkɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm. "ɹænd? wʌt wɑz ðæt? wʌd jə si ɪn ðɛm?"

Three Maidens split from those watching over Rand, darting after the two former nobles. Min stepped up to Rand, taking his arm. "Rand? What was that? What did you see in them?"

"ðə taɪm fəɹ haɪɾɪŋ ɪz pæst, mɪn. ðə ʃædoʊ meɪɾ ɪts pleɪ fəɹ mi ən lɔst. ɪts wɔɹ, nɑt sʌbtɝfjudʒ, ðət tɝnz ðə deɪ naʊ."

"The time for hiding is past, Min. The Shadow made its play for me and lost. It is war, not subterfuge, that turns the day now."

"soʊ ðəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz?" mɪn æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"So they're Darkfriends?" Min asked, frowning.

ɹænd tɝn tə hɝ, smaɪlɪŋ. "ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə θɹɛt. aɪ - " hi kʌɾ ɔf sʌɾənli, lʊkɪŋ tə ðə saɪd. mɪn tɝnd, ən ɡɹu tʃɪl.

Rand turned to her, smiling. "They are no longer a threat. I - " He cut off suddenly, looking to the side. Min turned, and grew chill.

tɑɹn ælθɹ stʊd nɪɹbaɪ. hi hæd dʒʌst wɔkt aʊɾ ʌv ə nɪɹbaɪ ɛntʃɹəns ɪndə ðə stoʊn, pɔzɪŋ ɑn ə loʊ sɛɾ ə stɛps liɾɪŋ daʊn tə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ɹændz ɪmoʊʃənz ɡɹu æpɹɪhɛnsɪv əɡɛn, ən mɪn ɹilaɪzd wʌt hid bɪn sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɝliɝ.

Tarn al'Thor stood nearby. He had just walked out of a nearby entrance into the Stone, pausing on a low set of steps leading down to the courtyard. Rand's emotions grew apprehensive again, and Min realized what he'd been searching for earlier.

tɑɹn lʊkt əɾ ɪz sʌn, fɔlɪŋ stɪl. hɪz hɛɹ wɑz ɡɹeɪ ən ɪz feɪs laɪnd, jɛɾ i wɑz sɑləɾ ɪn ə weɪ ðət fju pipəl wɝ.

Tarn looked at his son, falling still. His hair was gray and his face lined, yet he was solid in a way that few people were.

ɹænd lɪftəɾ ɪz hænd, ən ðə kɹaʊd - ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnkluɾəd - pɑɹɾəd. ɹænd pæs θɹu ðɛm, mɪn fɑloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, kɹɔsɪŋ tə ðə stɛps ʌp ðə stoʊn. ɹænd klaɪmd ə fju ʌv ðoʊz stɛps, hɛzɪɾənt.

Rand lifted his hand, and the crowd - Aes Sedai included - parted. Rand passed through them, Min following behind, crossing to the steps up the Stone. Rand climbed a few of those steps, hesitant.

ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd fɛl saɪlənt; ivən ðə ɡʌlz stɑp kɔlɪŋ.

The courtyard fell silent; even the gulls stopped calling.

ɹænd stɑpt ɑn ðə stɛps, ən mɪn kəd fil ɪz ɹɪlʌktəns, hɪz heɪm, hɪz tɛɹɝ. ɪt sim soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ. ɹænd - hu hæd feɪs fɔɹseɪkən wɪθaʊɾ ə tʃɹɛmɝ - wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪz fɑðɝ.

Rand stopped on the steps, and Min could feel his reluctance, his hame, his terror. It seemed so strange. Rand - who had faced Forsaken without a tremor - was afraid of his father.

ɹænd tʊk ðə læs fju stɛps ɪn tu sʌɾən stʃɹaɪdz ən ɡɹæb tɑɹn ɪn ən ɛmbɹeɪs. hi stʊd wʌn stɛp daʊn, wɪtʃ bɹɔɾ əm nɪɹ ən ikwəl haɪt. ɪn fækt, ɪn ðət pɑstʃɝ, tɑɹn ɔlmoʊst simd ə dʒaɪənt, ən ɹænd bʌɾ ə tʃaɪld u wɑz klɪŋɪŋ tə hɪm.

Rand took the last few steps in two sudden strides and grabbed Tarn in an embrace. He stood one step down, which brought them near an equal height. In fact, in that posture, Tarn almost seemed a giant, and Rand but a child who was clinging to him.

ðɛɹ, hoʊldɪŋ tə hɪz fɑðɝ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn bɪɡæn tə wip.

There, holding to his father, the Dragon Reborn began to weep.

ðə ɡæðɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, tɛɹənz ən il wɑtʃt sɔləmli. nʌn ʃʌfəld əɹ tɝn əweɪ. ɹænd skwizd ɪz aɪz ʃʌt. "aɪm sɑɹi, fɑðɝ," hi wɪspɝd. mɪn kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ. "aɪm soʊ sɑɹi."

The gathered Aes Sedai, Tairens and Aiel watched solemnly. None shuffled or turned away. Rand squeezed his eyes shut. "I'm sorry, Father," he whispered. Min could barely hear. "I'm so sorry."

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt, sʌn. ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt."

"It's all right, son. It's all right."

"aɪv dʌn soʊ mʌtʃ ðəɾ ɪz tɛɹəbəl."

"I've done so much that is terrible."

"noʊbɑdi wɔks ə dɪfəkəl pæθ wɪθaʊt stʌmbəlɪŋ naʊ ən əɡɛn. ɪt dɪdn bɹeɪk jə wən jə fɛl. ðæts ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt pɑɹt."

"Nobody walks a difficult path without stumbling now and again. It didn't break you when you fell. That's the important part."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. ðeɪ hɛld itʃ ʌðɝ fəɹ ə taɪm. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɹænd pʊl bæk, ðən dʒɛstʃɝd tə mɪn, stændɪŋ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə stɛps.

Rand nodded. They held each other for a time. Eventually, Rand pulled back, then gestured to Min, standing at the base of the steps.

"kʌm, fɑðɝ," ɹænd sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmwʌn aɪ wɑnə ɪntʃɹədus tə ju."

"Come, Father," Rand said. "There is someone I want to introduce to you."

tɑɹn tʃʌkəld. "ɪts bɪn θɹi deɪz, ɹænd. aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi mɛt hɝ."

Tarn chuckled. "It's been three days, Rand. I've already met her."

"jɛs, bʌt / dɪdn ɪntʃɹədus ju. aɪ nid tə." hi weɪv tə mɪn, ən ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. hi lʊkt əɾ əɹ pliɾɪŋli, soʊ ʃi saɪɾ ən klaɪmd ʌp ðə stɛps.

"Yes, but / didn't introduce you. I need to." He waved to Min, and she raised an eyebrow, folding her arms. He looked at her pleadingly, so she sighed and climbed up the steps.

"fɑðɝ," ɹænd sɛd, ɹɛstɪŋ ɪz hæn ɑn mɪnz bæk. "ðɪs ɪz mɪn fɑɹ-ʃɔ. ən ʃiz vɛɹi spɛʃəl tə mi."

"Father," Rand said, resting his hand on Min's back. "This is Min Far-shaw. And she's very special to me."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin


CHAPTER 14

eɪ vaʊ


A Vow

ɛɡwin wɔkt ʌp ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə dʒɛntəl sloʊp, ðə ɡɹæs ɡɹin əɾ əɹ fit, ði ɛɹ kul ən plɛzənt.

Egwene walked up the side of a gentle slope, the grass green at her feet, the air cool and pleasant.

leɪzi bʌɾɝflaɪz floʊɾəd fɹəm blɑsəm tə blɑsəm, laɪk kjʊɹiəs tʃɪlʒɹən pikɪŋ ɪndə kʌbɝdz.

Lazy butterflies floated from blossom to blossom, like curious children peeking into cupboards.

ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ ʃuz vænɪʃ soʊ ʃi kəd fil ðə bleɪdz bɪniθ əɹ fit.

Egwene made her shoes vanish so she could feel the blades beneath her feet.

ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, smaɪlɪŋ, ðən lʊkt ʌp ət ðə bɔɪlɪŋ blæk klaʊdz. æŋɡɹi, vaɪələnt, saɪlən dɪspaɪt flæʃɪz ʌv æmɪθɪs laɪtnɪŋ. tɛɹəbəl stɔɹm əbʌv, kwaɪət, plæsəd mɛdoʊ bɪniθ. ə daɪkɑɾəmi ʌv ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz.

She took a deep breath, smiling, then looked up at the boiling black clouds. Angry, violent, silent despite flashes of amethyst lightning. Terrible storm above, quiet, placid meadow beneath. A dichotomy of the World of Dreams.

ɑdli, tɛlɝɑnɹbiəd fɛl mɔɹ ənnætʃɹəl tə hɝ naʊ ðən ɪt hæd dʊɹɪŋ əɹ fɝs fju vɪzəts juzɪŋ vɛɹɪnz tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ʃid tʃɹiɾəd ðɪs pleɪs laɪk ə pleɪɡɹaʊnd, tʃeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ kloʊðz ɑn ə wɪm, əsumɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz seɪf. ʃi hædn ʌndɝstʊd. tɛlɝɑnɹbiəd wɑz əbaʊɾ əz seɪf əz ə bɛɹ tʃɹæp peɪntəɾ ə pɹɪɾi kʌlɝ. ɪf ðə waɪz wʌnz hædn stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ aʊt, ʃi maɪt nɑɾ əv lɪv tə bɪkʌm æmɪɝlɪn.

Oddly, Tel'aran'rbiod felt more unnatural to her now than it had during her first few visits using Verin's ter'angreal. She'd treated this place like a playground, changing her clothes on a whim, assuming that she was safe. She hadn't understood. Tel'aran'rbiod was about as safe as a bear trap painted a pretty color. If the Wise Ones hadn't straightened her out, she might not have lived to become Amyrlin.

jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz ɪt. ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ ɡɹin hɪlz, ðə stænz ə tʃɹiz. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs pleɪs ʃid kʌm, wɛl oʊvɝ ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ minɪŋfəl əbaʊt stændɪŋ hɪɹ, hævɪŋ kʌm soʊ fɑɹ. ən jɛɾ ɪt simd ʃi wəɾ əv tə kʌvɝ ən ikwəl dɪstəns bɪfɔɹ ðɪs wɑz dʌn, ən ɪn fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾɝ ə taɪm.

Yes, I think this is it. The rolling green hills, the stands of trees. It was the first place she'd come, well over a year ago. There was something meaningful about standing here, having come so far. And yet it seemed she would have to cover an equal distance before this was done, and in far shorter a time.

wən ʃid bɪn kæptɪv ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ʃi hæd ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf - -ɹɪpiɾɪdli - ðət ʃi kəd foʊkəs ɑn oʊnli wʌn pɹɑbləm əɾ ə taɪm. ðə ɹiunəfəkeɪʃən ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd tə kʌm fɝst. naʊ, haʊɛvɝ, boʊθ pɹɑbləmz ən pɑsəbəl səluʃənz simd ʌnkaʊntəbəl. ðeɪ oʊvɝwɛlmd əɹ dʒɹaʊnɪŋ əɹ ɪn ɔl ə ðə θɪŋz ʃi ʃəɾ i duɪŋ.

When she'd been captive in the Tower, she had reminded herself - -repeatedly - that she could focus on only one problem at a time. The reunification of the White Tower had to come first. Now, however, both problems and possible solutions seemed uncountable. They overwhelmed her drowning her in all of the things she should he doing.

fɔɹtʃənətli, dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs fju deɪz, sɛvɹəl ʌnɪkspɛktɪd stɔɹz ʌv ɡɹeɪn hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ɪn wʌn keɪs ə fɝɡɑɾən wɛɹhaʊs, oʊn baɪ ə mæn u hæd daɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə wɪntɝ. ði ʌðɝz wɝ smɔlɝ, ə fju sæks hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ. ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, nʌn ə ðɛm hæd bɔɹn ɛni kaɪndə ɹɑt.

Fortunately, during the last few days, several unexpected stores of grain had been discovered in the city. In one case a forgotten warehouse, owned by a man who had died over the winter. The others were smaller, a few sacks here and there. Remarkably, none of them had borne any kind of rot.

ʃi hæd tu miɾɪŋz ðɪs ivnɪŋ, dilɪŋ wɪð ʌðɝ pɹɑbləmz. hɝ bɪɡəs dɪfəkəlti wɑz gɑnə bi ðə pɝsɛpʃənz ə ðə pipəl ʃi mɛt wɪð. niðɝ ɡɹup wəd si hɝ əz wʌt ʃi hæd bɪkʌm.

She had two meetings this evening, dealing with other problems. Her biggest difficulty was going to be the perceptions of the people she met with. Neither group would see her as what she had become.

ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, wɪlɪŋ hɝsɛlf əweɪ. wən ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ ɹum, dipli ʃæɾoʊd ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝz, ɪts kɑləmz ɹaɪzɪŋ laɪk θɪk taʊɝz. ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ.

She closed her eyes, willing herself away. When she opened her eyes, she was standing in a large room, deeply shadowed in the corners, its columns rising like thick towers. The Heart of the Stone of Tear.

tu waɪz wʌnz sæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ət ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum, əmɪɾ ə fɔɹəst ə kɑləmz. əbʌv ðɛɹ laɪt bɹaʊn skɝts ən waɪt blaʊsəz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ dɪstɪŋkli dɪfɹənt. bɛɹz wɑz ɹɪŋkəld wɪð eɪdʒ, laɪk lɛðɝ lɛf tə kjʊɹ ɪn ðə sʌn. fəɹ ɔl əɹ əkeɪʒənəl stɝnnəs, smaɪl laɪnz woʊv fɹəm əɹ aɪz ən maʊθ.

Two Wise Ones sat on the floor at the center of the room, amid a forest of columns. Above their light brown skirts and white blouses, their faces were distinctly different. Bair's was wrinkled with age, like leather left to cure in the sun. For all her occasional sternness, smile lines wove from her eyes and mouth.

æmɪz' feɪs wɑz sɪlki smuð, ən ɪfɛkt ə biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl. hɝ feɪs wɑz nɑɾ eɪdʒləs, bʌt ʃi cʊɾə bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ði ɪmoʊʃən ʃi ʃoʊd.

Amys' face was silky smooth, an effect of being able to channel. Her face was not ageless, but she could have been Aes Sedai for the emotion she showed.

ðə tu hæd ðɛɹ ʃɔlz ət ðɛɹ weɪsts, ðɛɹ blaʊsəz ənleɪst. ɛɡwin sæt bɪfɔɹ əm bʌt lɛf hɝsɛlf wɛɹɪŋ wɛtləndɝ kloʊðɪŋ. æmɪz ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ; wɑz ʃi θɪŋkɪŋ ðəɾ ɛɡwin ʃəɾ əv tʃeɪnʒd? əɹ dɪd ʃi əpɹiʃieɪt ðəɾ ɛɡwin dɪd nɑɾ ɪməteɪt sʌmθɪŋ ʃi wɑz nɑt? ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl.

The two had their shawls at their waists, their blouses unlaced. Egwene sat before them but left herself wearing wetlander clothing. Amys raised an eyebrow; was she thinking that Egwene should have changed? Or did she appreciate that Egwene did not imitate something she was not? It was difficult to tell.

"ðə bæɾəl wɪðɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz oʊvɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"The battle within the White Tower is over," Egwene said.

"ðə wʊmən ɪleɪɾə ɹɔɪhən?" æmɪz æskt.

"The woman Elaida a'Roihan?" Amys asked.

"teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ hæv bɪn æksɛptɪɾ əz æmɪɹ-lɪn baɪ ðoʊz u fɑloʊd hɝ. maɪ pəzɪʃən ɪz fɑɹ fɹəm sɪkjʊɹ - ət taɪmz, aɪ fil bælənst ətɑp ə stoʊn ðət sɪts bælənst ətɑp ənʌðɝ stoʊn. bʌt ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz əɡɛn hoʊl."

"Taken by the Seanchan," Egwene said. "I have been accepted as Amyr-lin by those who followed her. My position is far from secure - at times, I feel balanced atop a stone that sits balanced atop another stone. But the White Tower is again whole."

æmɪz klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ sɔfli. ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hæn ən ə stʃɹaɪp stoʊl - ən æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl -  əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪt. "aɪ səpoʊz jə ʃəd bi wɛɹɪŋ ðɪs, ðɛn."

Amys clicked her tongue softly. She raised her hand and a striped stole - an Amyrlin's stole -  appeared in it. "I suppose you should be wearing this, then."

ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɑft, sloʊ bɹɛθ. ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl tə hɝ, səmtaɪmz, haʊ mʌtʃ stɑk ʃi pʊɾ ɪn ði əpɪnjənz ə ðiz wɪmən. ʃi tʊk ðə stoʊl, pʊɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

Egwene let out a soft, slow breath. It was remarkable to her, sometimes, how much stock she put in the opinions of these women. She took the stole, putting it around her shoulders.

sɔɹɪliə wɪl dɪslaɪk ðɪs nuz," bɛɹ sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "ʃi stɪl hæɾ ə hoʊp ðət jə wəd liv ðoʊz fulz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ɹɪtɝn tə ʌs."

Sorilea will dislike this news," Bair said, shaking her head. "She still had a hope that you would leave those fools in the White Tower and return to us."

"pliz teɪk kɛɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd, sʌmənɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti. "aɪ æm nɑɾ oʊnli wʌn ə ðoʊz fulz, maɪ fɹɛnd, bʌɾ aɪm ðɛɹ liɾɝ. kwin ə ðə fulz, jə maɪt seɪ."

"Please take care," Egwene said, summoning herself a cup of tea. "I am not only one of those fools, my friend, but I am their leader. Queen of the fools, you might say."

bɛɹ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ hæv toʊ."

Bair hesitated. "I have toh."

"nɑt fəɹ spikɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ," ɛɡwin əʃʊɹd hɝ. "mɛni ʌv əm ɑɹ fulz, bʌɾ ɑɹ wi nɑɾ ɔl fulz ət səm pɔɪnt? jə dɪd nɑɾ əbændən mi tə maɪ feɪljɝz wən jə faʊn mi wɔkɪŋ tɛlɝɑnɹbiəd. ɪn laɪk mænɝ bækslæʃ kænɑɾ əbændən ðoʊz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"Not for speaking the truth," Egwene assured her. "Many of them are fools, but are we not all fools at some point? You did not abandon me to my failures when you found me walking Tel'aran'rbiod. In like manner \ cannot abandon those of the White Tower."

æmɪz' aɪz nɛɹoʊd. "ju hæv ɡɹoʊn mʌtʃ sɪns wi læs mɛt, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ."

Amys' eyes narrowed. "You have grown much since we last met, Egwene al'Vere."

ðət sɛn ə θɹɪl θɹu ɛɡwin. "aɪ hæd mʌtʃ nid tə ɡɹoʊ. maɪ laɪf əz bɪn dɪfəkəlt ə leɪt."

That sent a thrill through Egwene. "I had much need to grow. My life has been difficult of late."

"wɛn kənfɹʌntəd baɪ ə kəlæpst ɹuf," bɛɹ sɛd, "sʌm wɪl bɪɡɪn tə hɔl əweɪ ðə ɹɛfjus, bɪkʌmɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ fəɹ ðə pɹɑsɛs. ʌðɝz wɪl ɡoʊ tə vɪzət ðɛɹ bɹʌðɝz hoʊld ən dʒɹɪŋk ɪz wɔɾɝ."

"When confronted by a collapsed roof," Bair said, "some will begin to haul away the refuse, becoming stronger for the process. Others will go to visit their brother's hold and drink his water."

"hæv jə sin ɹænd ɹisənli?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Have you seen Rand recently?" Egwene asked.

"ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn əz ɛmbɹeɪs dɛθ," æmɪz sɛd. "hi hæz ɡɪvən ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ðə stoʊnz, ən əz ɪnstɛɾ ətʃiv ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðə wɪnd."

"The Car'a'carn has embraced death," Amys said. "He has given up trying to be as strong as the stones, and has instead achieved the strength of the wind."

bɛɹ nɑɾəd. "ɔlmoʊst, wɪl əv tə stɑp kɔlɪŋ ɪm ə tʃaɪld." ʃi smaɪld. "ɔlmoʊst."

Bair nodded. "Almost, we will have to stop calling him a child." She smiled. "Almost."

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv noʊ hɪn ə hɝ ʃɑk. ʃiɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə bi dɪsplizd wɪð ɹænd. "aɪ wɪʃ jə tə noʊ ðə ɹɪspɛkt aɪ hæv fəɹ ju. juv mʌtʃ ɑnɝ fəɹ teɪkɪŋ mi ɪn əz jə dɪd. aɪ θɪŋk ðət ði oʊnli ɹizən aɪ si fɑɹðɝ ðən maɪ sɪstɝz ɪz kəz jə tɔt mi tə wɔk wɪð maɪ bæk stʃɹeɪɾ ən hɛd haɪ."

Egwene gave no hint of her shock. She'd expected them to be displeased with Rand. "I wish you to know the respect I have for you. You have much honor for taking me in as you did. I think that the only reason I see farther than my sisters is because you taught me to walk with my back straight and head high."

"ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl θɪŋ," æmɪz sɛd, ɑbviəsli plizd. "wʌn ðəɾ ɛni wʊmən wəɾ əv dʌn."

"It was a simple thing," Amys said, obviously pleased. "One that any woman would have done."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ fju plɛʒɝz mɔɹ sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ ðən teɪkɪŋ ə kɔɹd sʌmwʌn ɛls əz nɑɾɪd," bɛɹ sɛd, "ðɛn tizɪŋ ɪt stʃɹeɪɾ əɡɛn. haʊɛvɝ, ɪf ðə kɔɹɾ ɪz nɑɾ ʌv ɡʊd mətɪɹiəl, ðən noʊ əntæŋlɪŋ wɪl seɪv ɪt. jə ɡeɪv əs faɪn mətɪɹiəl, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ."

"There are few pleasures more satisfying than taking a cord someone else has knotted," Bair said, "then teasing it straight again. However, if the cord is not of good material, then no untangling will save it. You gave us fine material, Egwene al'Vere."

"aɪ wɪʃ ðət ðəɹ wɝ ə weɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "tə tʃɹeɪn mɔɹ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə weɪz ə ðə waɪz wʌnz."

"I wish that there were a way," Egwene said, "to train more sisters in the ways of the Wise Ones."

"ju kəd sɛn əm tə ʌs," æmɪz sɛd. "pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪf ðeɪ nid pʌnɪʃɪŋ. wi wʊdn kɑɾəl əm laɪk ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"You could send them to us," Amys said. "Particularly if they need punishing. We wouldn't coddle them like the White Tower."

ɛɡwin bɹɪsəld. ðə biɾɪŋz ʃid teɪkən hæd bɪn "kɑɾəlɪŋ"? ðət wɑz ə faɪt ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə dʒɔɪn, haʊɛvɝ. ði il wəɾ ɔlweɪz əsum wɛtləndɝ weɪz tə bi sɑft, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðəɾ əsʌmpʃən.

Egwene bristled. The beatings she'd taken had been "coddling"? That was a fight she didn't want to join, however. The Aiel would always assume wetlander ways to be soft, and there was no changing that assumption.

"aɪ daʊt ðə sɪstɝz wəɾ əɡɹi tə ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd kɛɹfəli. "bʌt hæt maɪt wɝk wəd bi tə sɛn jʌŋ wɪmən - ðoʊz stɪl tʃɹeɪn- .__tə stʌɾi wɪð ju. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv waɪ maɪ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɑz soʊ ɪfɪk- tɪv; aɪ wɑzn jɛt sɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ." "wʊd ðeɪ əɡɹi tə ðɪs?" bɛɹ æskt.

"I doubt the sisters would agree to that," Egwene said carefully. "But hat might work would be to send young women - those still train- .__to study with you. That was part of why my training was so effec- tive; I wasn't yet set in the ways of the Aes Sedai." "Would they agree to this?" Bair asked.

"ðeɪ maɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪf wi sɛn æksɛptɪd. nɑvəsɪz wəd bi ɑnsɪɾɝd tu ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst, sɪstɝz tu dɪɡnəfaɪd. bʌɾ æksɛptɪd . . . pɝhæps. ðəɹ wəd nid tə bi ə ɡʊd ɹizən ðət simz tə bɛnəfɪt ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"They might," Egwene said. "If we sent Accepted. Novices would be onsidered too inexperienced, sisters too dignified. But Accepted . . . perhaps. There would need to be a good reason that seems to benefit the White Tower."

"ju ʃəd tɛl əm tə ɡoʊ," bɛɹ sɛd, "æn ɪkspɛkt əm tə oʊbeɪ.

"You should tell them to go," Bair said, "and expect them to obey.

hæv jə nɑt ðə moʊst ɑnɝ əmʌŋ ðɛm? ʃəd ðeɪ nɑt lɪsən tə jəɹ kaʊnsəl wən ɪts waɪz?"

Have you not the most honor among them? Should they not listen to your counsel when it is wise?"

"dʌz ðə klæn ɔlweɪz də əz ə tʃif dɪmænz?" ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Does the clan always do as a chief demands?" Egwene said.

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," æmɪz sɛd. "bʌt wɛtləndɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz fɔnɪŋ oʊvɝ kɪŋz ən lɔɹdz. ðeɪ sim tə laɪk biɪŋ toʊld wʌt tə du. ɪt meɪks əm fil seɪf."

"Of course not," Amys said. "But wetlanders are always fawning over kings and lords. They seem to like being told what to do. It makes them feel safe."

"ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ dɪfɹənt," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Aes Sedai are different," Egwene said.

"ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kip ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðət wi ʃəɾ ɔl bi tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ," æmɪz sɛd. hɝ toʊn ɪndəkeɪɾəd wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðəɾ aɪdiə. "ðeɪ dʒɹoʊn ɑn, əz nɔɪzi əz ə blaɪn tʃɪpəbɝd ðət kænɑt tɛl ɪf ɪts deɪ əɹ naɪt. ðeɪ nid tə si ðət wɪl nɛvɝ də sətʃ ə θɪŋ. tɛl əm ðət jəɹ sɛndɪŋ wɪmən tə əs tə stʌɾi əɹ weɪz soʊ wi kən ʌndɝstænd wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪts oʊnli ðə tʃɹuθ;

"The Aes Sedai keep implying that we should all be training in the White Tower," Amys said. Her tone indicated what she thought of that idea. "They drone on, as noisy as a blind chippabird that cannot tell if it's day or night. They need to see that we will never do such a thing. Tell them that you're sending women to us to study our ways so we can understand one another. It is only the truth;

ðeɪ nidnt noʊ ðət jə ɔlsoʊ ɪkspɛkt əm tə bi stʃɹɛŋθən baɪ ði ɪkspɪɹiəns."

they needn't know that you also expect them to be strengthened by the experience."

"ðæt maɪt wɝk." ɛɡwin wɑz plizd; ðə plæn wɑz oʊnli ə fju hɛɹz ɔf fɹəm wʌt ʃi ɪvɛntʃəwəli wɑntəd tə əkɑmplɪʃ.

"That might work." Egwene was pleased; the plan was only a few hairs off from what she eventually wanted to accomplish.

"ðɪs ɪz ə tɑpɪk tə kənsɪɾɝ ɪn iziɝ deɪz," bɛɹ sɛd. "aɪ sɛns ɡɹeɪɾɝ tʃɹʌbəl ɪn jə ðən ðɪs, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ."

"This is a topic to consider in easier days," Bair said. "I sense greater trouble in you than this, Egwene al'Vere."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ tʃɹʌbəl," ʃi sɛd. "ɹæn ælθɹ. hæz i toʊl jə wʌɾ i dɪklɛɹd wən i vɪzəɾəd ðə waɪt taʊɝ?"

"There is a greater trouble," she said. "Rand al'Thor. Has he told you what he declared when he visited the White Tower?"

"hi sɛɾ i æŋɡɝd ju," æmɪz sɛd. "aɪ faɪn ɪz ækʃənz ɑd. hi vɪzəts jə æftɝ ɔl ɪz tɔk ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɑkɪŋ ɪm ʌp ən pʊɾɪŋ ɪm ɪn ə bɑks?"

"He said he angered you," Amys said. "I find his actions odd. He visits you after all his talk of the Aes Sedai locking him up and putting him in a box?"

"hi wɑz . . . dɪfɹənt wən i keɪm hɪɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "hi hæz ɛmbɹeɪs dɛθ," bɛɹ sɛɾ əɡɛn, nɑɾɪŋ. "hi bɪkʌmz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn tʃɹuli."

"He was . . . different when he came here," Egwene said. "He has embraced death," Bair said again, nodding. "He becomes the Car'a'carn truly."

hi spoʊk paʊɝfli," ɛɡwin sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪz wɝdz wɝ ðoʊz ə mædnəs. hi sɛd hiz gɑnə bɹeɪk ðə silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən." æmɪz ən bɛɹ boʊθ fɹoʊz. jə ɑɹ sɝɾən ə ðɪs?" bɛɹ æskt. "jɛs."

He spoke powerfully," Egwene said, "but his words were those of madness. He said he is going to break the seals on the Dark One's prison." Amys and Bair both froze. You are certain of this?" Bair asked. "Yes."

"ðɪs ɪz dɪstɝbɪŋ nuz," æmɪz sɛd. "wi wɪl kənsʌlt wɪð ɪm ɑn ðɪs. θæŋk jə fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ ðɪs tə ʌs."

"This is disturbing news," Amys said. "We will consult with him on this. Thank you for bringing this to us."

"aɪ wɪl bi ɡæðɝɪŋ ðoʊz u ɹɪzɪs hɪm." ɛɡwin ɹɪlækst. əntɪl ðət moʊmənt, ʃi hædn bɪn sɝɾən wɪtʃ weɪ ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd ɡoʊ. "pɝhæps ɹænd wɪl lɪsən tə ɹizən ɪf ɪnʌf vɔɪsəz ɑɹ pɹɛzənt."

"I will be gathering those who resist him." Egwene relaxed. Until that moment, she hadn't been certain which way the Wise Ones would go. "Perhaps Rand will listen to reason if enough voices are present."

"hi ɪz nɑt noʊn fəɹ ɪz wɪlɪŋnəs tə lɪsən tə ɹizən," æmɪz sɛd wɪð ə saɪ, ɹaɪzɪŋ. ɛɡwin ən bɛɹ dɪd soʊ əz wɛl. ðə waɪz wʌnz' blaʊsəz wɝ leɪst ɪn ən ɪnstənt.

"He is not known for his willingness to listen to reason," Amys said with a sigh, rising. Egwene and Bair did so as well. The Wise Ones' blouses were laced in an instant.

"ðə taɪm ɪz lɔŋ pæs fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz" ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɔɹ fəɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz tə əvɔɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. wi mʌst wɝk təɡɛðɝ. hæn ɪn hæn əz sɪstɝz."

"The time is long past for the White Tower to ignore the Wise Ones" Egwene said, "or for the Wise Ones to avoid the Aes Sedai. We must work together. Hand in hand as sisters."

"soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪɾ ɪzən səm sʌn-blaɪndɪd ɹɪdɪkjələs θɔɾ əbaʊt ðə waɪz wʌnz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ," bɛɹ sɛd. ʃi smaɪl tə ʃoʊ ɪt wɑz ə dʒoʊk, bʌt səksiɾəd oʊnli ɪn bɛɹɪŋ əɹ tiθ.

"So long as it isn't some sun-blinded ridiculous thought about the Wise Ones training in the Tower," Bair said. She smiled to show it was a joke, but succeeded only in baring her teeth.

ɛɡwin smaɪld. ʃi dɪd wɑn ðə waɪz wʌnz tə tʃɹeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni mɛθədz ə tʃænəlɪŋ ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd bɛɾɝ ðən ðə waɪz wʌnz. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ bɛɾɝ əbaʊt wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ən - ɛɡwin ədmɪɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli - wɪð liɾɝʃɪp.

Egwene smiled. She did want the Wise Ones to train in the Tower. There were many methods of channeling that the Aes Sedai did better than the Wise Ones. On the other hand, the Wise Ones were better about working together and - Egwene admitted reluctantly - with leadership.

ðə tu ɡɹups kəd lɝn mʌtʃ fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ. ʃi wəd faɪn ə weɪ tə taɪ ðɛm təɡɛðɝ.

The two groups could learn much from one another. She would find a way to tie them together.

sʌmhaʊ.

Somehow.

ʃi fɑnli beɪd fɛɹwɛl tə ðə tu waɪz wʌnz, wɑtʃɪŋ əz ðeɪ feɪɾəd fɹəm tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

She fondly bade farewell to the two Wise Ones, watching as they faded from Tel'aran'rhiod.

wəd ðət ðɛɹ kaʊnsəl əloʊn pɹuvd ɪnʌf tə tɝn ɹænd fɹəm ɪz ɪnseɪn plæn. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli.

Would that their counsel alone proved enough to turn Rand from his insane plan. But it was unlikely.

ɛɡwin tʊk ə bɹɛθ. ɪn ən ɪnstənt ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, hɝ fit plæntəd dɝɛkli ɑn ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn peɪntəɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. sɛvən spaɪɹəlz ə kʌlɝ waʊn aʊt fɹəm hɝ, spɪnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə pɝɪməɾɝ ə ðə doʊm tʃeɪmbɝ.

Egwene took a breath. In an instant she stood in the Hall of the Tower, her feet planted directly on the Flame of Tar Valon painted on the floor. Seven spirals of color wound out from her, spinning toward the perimeter of the domed chamber.

nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. ɛɡwin dʒɹu hɝ lɪps tə ə laɪn. ðət wʊmən! ɛɡwin kəd bɹɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə ɪts niz, tɝn ə stɔntʃ mɛmbɝ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ tə hɝ saɪd, ɝn ðə ɹɪspɛkt ə ðə tʌfəst waɪz wʌnz. bʌt laɪt hɛlp əɹ ɪf ʃi niɾəd ðə lɔɪəlti ʌv əɹ fɹɛnz! ɹænd, ɡɔɪn, nɪneɪiv - ɔl ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn weɪz.

Nynaeve was not there. Egwene drew her lips to a line. That woman! Egwene could bring the White Tower to its knees, turn a staunch member of the Red Ajah to her side, earn the respect of the toughest Wise Ones. But Light help her if she needed the loyalty of her friends! Rand, Gawyn, Nynaeve - all infuriating in their own ways.

ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz tə weɪt. pɝhæps nɪneɪiv wəd stɪl kʌm. ɪf nɑt, ðɪs wʊdn bi ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi hæd dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɛɡwin. ə mæsɪv ɹoʊz wɪndoʊ dɑməneɪɾəd ðə fɑɹ wɔl bɪhaɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪtsɛlf. ðə fleɪm ət ðə sɛntɝ spɑɹkəld, əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ sʌnlaɪt bɪɑnd, ðoʊ ɛɡwin nu ðoʊz bɔɪlɪŋ blæk klaʊdz kʌvɝɾ ɔl ðə skaɪ ʌv ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz.

She folded her arms to wait. Perhaps Nynaeve would still come. If not, this wouldn't be the first time she had disappointed Egwene. A massive rose window dominated the far wall behind the Amyrlin Seat itself. The Flame at the center sparkled, as if there were sunlight beyond, though Egwene knew those boiling black clouds covered all the sky of the World of Dreams.

ʃi tɝn fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ, ðən fɹoʊz.

She turned from the window, then froze.

ðɛɹ, sɛɾ ɪndə ðə ɡlæs bɪloʊ ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ sɛɡmən ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ. ðət wɑzn pɑɹɾ ə ði ɝɪdʒənəl wɪndoʊ. ɛɡwin stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə ɡlæs.

There, set into the glass below the Flame of Tar Valon, was a large segment in the shape of the Dragon's Fang. That wasn't part of the original window. Egwene stepped forward, inspecting the glass.

ðəɹ ɪz ə θɝd kɑnstən bɪsaɪdz ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ən ðə dɑɹk wʌn, vɛɹɪnz mi-tɪkjələs vɔɪs sɛd, ə mɛmɹi fɹəm ənʌðɝ taɪm. ðəɹ ɪz ə wɝl ðət laɪz ɪθən itʃ ə ðiz ʌðɝz, ɪnsaɪɾ ɔl ə ðɛm ət ðə seɪm taɪm. əɹ pɝhæps sɝɾɪldə ɹaʊndɪŋ ðɛm. ɹaɪɾɝz ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz kɔld ɪt tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

There is a third constant besides the Creator and the Dark One, Verin's me-ticulous voice said, a memory from another time. There is a world that lies ithin each of these others, inside all of them at the same time. Or perhaps sur~ rounding them. Writers in the Age of Legends called it Tel'aran'rhiod.

dɪd ðɪs wɪndoʊ ɹɛpɹəzɛnt wʌn ə ðoʊz, ənʌðɝ wɝld wɛɹ dʒɹæɡən ən æmɪɝlɪn ɹul tɑɹ vəlɑn saɪd baɪ saɪd?

Did this window represent one of those, another world where Dragon and Amyrlin ruled Tar Valon side by side?

"ðæts ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ wɪndoʊ," ə vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"That's an interesting window," a voice said from behind her.

ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd, spɪnɪŋ. nɪneɪiv stʊd ðɛɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs ə bɹaɪt jɛloʊ tʃɹɪmd wɪð ɡɹin əkɹɔs ðə haɪ bɑɾəs ən əlɔŋ ðə skɝt. ʃi wɔɹ ə ɹɛd dɑɾ ət ðə sɛntɝ ə hɝ fɔɹhɛd, ən hæɾ əɹ hɛɹ woʊvən ɪndə ɪts kɛɹəktɝɪstɪk bɹeɪd.

Egwene started, spinning. Nynaeve stood there, wearing a dress of bright yellow trimmed with green across the high bodice and along the skirt. She wore a red dot at the center of her forehead, and had her hair woven into its characteristic braid.

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ə ɹɪlif. faɪnəli! ɪt hæd bɪn mʌnθs sɪns ʃid sin nɪneɪiv. kɝsɪŋ ɪnsaɪd fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf bi sɝpɹaɪzd, ʃi smuðd əɹ feɪs ən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, wivɪŋ spɪɹət. ə fju ɪnvɝɾɪd wɔɹdz maɪt hɛlp kip əɹ fɹəm biɪŋ stɑɹɾəld əɡɛn. ɪleɪn wɑz səpoʊz tə ɝaɪv ə lɪɾəl leɪɾɝ.

Egwene felt a surge of relief. Finally! It had been months since she'd seen Nynaeve. Cursing inside for letting herself be surprised, she smoothed her face and embraced the Source, weaving Spirit. A few inverted wards might help keep her from being startled again. Elayne was supposed to arrive a little later.

"aɪ dɪdn tʃuz ðɪs pæɾɝn," ɛɡwin sɛd, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət ðə ɹoʊz wɪndoʊ. "ðɪs ɪz tɛlɝɑnɹhiədz ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃən."

"I didn't choose this pattern," Egwene said, looking back at the Rose Window. "This is Tel'aran'rhiod's interpretation."

"bʌt ðə wɪndoʊ ɪtsɛlf ɪz ɹil?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"But the window itself is real?" Nynaeve asked.

"ənfɔɹtʃənətli," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌn ə ðə hoʊlz ðə sintʃæn lɛft wən ðeɪ ətækt."

"Unfortunately," Egwene said. "One of the holes the Seanchan left when they attacked."

"ðeɪ ətækt}" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"They attacked}" Nynaeve asked.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. sʌmθɪŋ jə wʊɾə noʊn ɪf juɾ ɛvɝ ɹɪspɑndɪd tə maɪ sʌmənz!

"Yes," Egwene said. Something you would have known if you'd ever responded to my summons!

nɪneɪiv foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, ən ðə tu ʌv əm ɹəɡɑɹɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn sɛntɝɪŋ ðə flɔɹ bɪniθ ðɛm. ðɪs wəɾ əv tə bi hændəl vɛɹi kɛɹfəli; nɪneɪiv kəd bi əz pɹɪkli əz ðə wɝst ə θɔɹnbəʃɪz.

Nynaeve folded her arms, and the two of them regarded one another across the room, Flame of Tar Valon centering the floor beneath them. This would have to be handled very carefully; Nynaeve could be as prickly as the worst of thornbushes.

'wɛl," nɪneɪiv sɛd, saʊndɪŋ dɪstɪŋkli ənkʌmftəɹbəl, "aɪ noʊ jəɹ bɪzi, ən laɪt noʊz aɪ hæv ɪnʌf θɪŋz tə bi duɪŋ. tɛl mi ðə nuz jə θɪŋk aɪ nid tə noʊ, ən əl bi ɔf."

'Well," Nynaeve said, sounding distinctly uncomfortable, "I know you're busy, and Light knows I have enough things to be doing. Tell me the news you think I need to know, and I'll be off."

"nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd, "aɪ dɪdn bɹɪŋ jə hɪɹ oʊnli tə ɡɪv jə nuz."

"Nynaeve," Egwene said, "I didn't bring you here only to give you news."

nɪneɪiv ɡɹæspt əɹ bɹeɪd. ʃi nu ʃi ʃəd bi ɹɪbjuk fəɹ ðə weɪ ʃiɾ əvɔɪɾəd ɛɡwin.

Nynaeve grasped her braid. She knew she should be rebuked for the way she'd avoided Egwene.

æktʃəli ," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud, "aɪ wɑntəd tə æsk jəɹ ædvaɪs."

Actually," Egwene continued, "I wanted to ask your advice."

nɪneɪiv blɪŋkt. "ædvaɪs ɑn wʌt?"

Nynaeve blinked. "Advice on what?"

wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə fleɪm, "jɔɹ wʌn ə ðə fju pipəl aɪ kən θɪŋk ə hu hæz bɪn ɪn ə sɪtʃueɪʃən sɪməlɝ tə maɪn."

Well," Egwene said, strolling across the Flame, "you're one of the few people I can think of who has been in a situation similar to mine."

"æmɪɝlɪn?" nɪneɪiv æsk flætli.

"Amyrlin?" Nynaeve asked flatly.

"ə liɾɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, pæsɪŋ nɪneɪiv ən nɑɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə wɔk bɪsaɪd hɝ, "ðæɾ ɛvɹiwʌn θɪŋks ɪz tu jʌŋ. hu ɹoʊz tə hɝ pəzɪʃən əbɹʌpli. hu noʊz ʃiz ðə ɹaɪt wʊmən fəɹ ðə dʒɑb, jɛɾ əz oʊnli ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ æksɛptəns fɹəm moʊst ə ðoʊz nɪɹ hɝ."

"A leader," Egwene said, passing Nynaeve and nodding for her to walk beside her, "that everyone thinks is too young. Who rose to her position abruptly. Who knows she is the right woman for the job, yet has only grudging acceptance from most of those near her."

"jɛs," nɪneɪiv sɛd, wɔkɪŋ wɪð ɛɡwin, aɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɪstənt. "ju aɪ kəd seɪ aɪ noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ə biɪŋ ɪn ðət sɪtʃueɪʃən."

"Yes," Nynaeve said, walking with Egwene, eyes growing distant. "You I could say I know something of being in that situation."

"haʊ dɪd jə dil wɪð ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt. "ɪt simz ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ du, aɪ nid tə də maɪsɛlf -  kəz ɪf aɪ doʊnt, ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹ mi wʌns aɪm aʊɾ ə saɪt. mɛni əsum ðəɾ aɪ ɡɪv ɔɹɾɝz dʒʌs tə bi sin meɪkɪŋ nɔɪz, əɹ ðeɪ ɹɪzɛn maɪ pəzɪʃən əbʌv ðɛm."

"How did you deal with it?" Egwene asked. "It seems that everything I do, I need to do myself -  because if I don't, they ignore me once I'm out of sight. Many assume that I give orders just to be seen making noise, or they resent my position above them."

"haʊ dɪɾ aɪ dil wɪð ɪt wən aɪ wɑz wɪzdəm?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "ɛɡwin, aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ dɪd. aɪ kəd bɛɹli kip maɪsɛlf fɹəm bɑksɪŋ dʒɑn θeɪnz ɪɹz hæf ðə deɪz, ən doʊnt ɡɛt mi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt sɛn!"

"How did I deal with it when I was Wisdom?" Nynaeve asked. "Egwene, I don't know if I did. I could barely keep myself from boxing Jon Thane's ears half the days, and don't get me talking about Cenn!"

"bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ ɹɪspɛktɪd ju."

"But eventually they respected you."

"ɪt wɑz ə mæɾɝ ə nɑt lɛɾɪŋ əm fɝɡɛt maɪ steɪʃən. ðeɪ kʊdn bi əlaʊd tə kəntɪnju tə θɪŋk ə mi əz ə jʌŋ ɡɝl. ɪstæblɪʃ jəɹ əθɔɹəɾi kwɪkli. bi fɝm wɪð ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ɛɡwin, kəz ðəl bɪɡɪn baɪ siɪŋ haʊ fɑɹ ðeɪ kən pʊʃ ju. ən wʌns juv lɛɾ əm pʊʃ jə ə hændspæn, ɪts hɑɹɾɝ ðən wɪntɝ məlæsəz tə ɡɛt bæk wʌt juv lɔst."

"It was a matter of not letting them forget my station. They couldn't be allowed to continue to think of me as a young girl. Establish your authority quickly. Be firm with the women in the Tower, Egwene, because they'll begin by seeing how far they can push you. And once you've let them push you a handspan, it's harder than winter molasses to get back what you've lost."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"All right," Egwene said.

"æn doʊn kʌm ʌp wɪð aɪɾəl wɝk fəɹ əm tə du," nɪneɪiv sɛd. ðeɪ pæst aʊɾ ə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz. "ɡɛɾ əm juz tə jə ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz, bʌt meɪk ðoʊz ɔɹɾɝz ɡʊd wʌnz. meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ doʊn baɪpæs ju. aɪd ɡɛs ðəɾ ɪt maɪt bi izi fəɹ əm tə stɑɹt lʊkɪŋ tə ðə sɪɾɝz əɹ ði ədʒɑ hɛdz ɪnstɛɾ ə ju; wɪmən ɪn ɛmənz fil stɑɹɾəd ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl ɪnstɛɾ ə mi.

"And don't come up with idle work for them to do," Nynaeve said. They passed out of the Hall of the Tower, strolling through the hallways. "Get them used to you giving orders, but make those orders good ones. Make sure they don't bypass you. I'd guess that it might be easy for them to start looking to the Sitters or the Ajah heads instead of you; women in Emond's Field started going to the Women's Circle instead of me.

"ɪf jə dɪskʌvɝ ðət ðə sɪɾɝz ɑɹ meɪkɪŋ dɪsɪʒənz ðət ʃʊɾə kʌm bɪfɔɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ hɔl, juv tə meɪk ə bɪɡ fʌs əbaʊɾ ɪt. tʃɹʌs mi. ðəl ɡɹaʊs ðət jəɹ meɪkɪŋ tu mʌtʃ nɔɪz oʊvɝ smɔl θɪŋz, bʌt ðəl θɪŋk twaɪs əbaʊt duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɪθaʊt jəɹ ətɛnʃən."

"If you discover that the Sitters are making decisions that should have come before the entire Hall, you have to make a big fuss about it. Trust me. They'll grouse that you're making too much noise over small things, but they'll think twice about doing something important without your attention."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. ɪt wɑz ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs, ðoʊ - ʌv kɔɹs - ɪt keɪm kʌlɝd baɪ nɪneɪivz vju ʌv ðə wɝld. "aɪ θɪŋk ðə bɪɡəs pɹɑbləm," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɪz ðəɾ aɪ hæv soʊ fju tʃɹu səpɔɹɾɝz."

Egwene nodded. It was good advice, though - of course - it came colored by Nynaeve's view of the world. "I think the biggest problem," Egwene said, "is that I have so few true supporters."

"ju hæv mi. ən ɪleɪn."

"You have me. And Elayne."

"du aɪ?" ɛɡwin sɛd, stɑpɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ ən lʊkɪŋ ət nɪneɪiv. "du aɪ ɹɪli hæv ju, nɪneɪiv?"

"Do I?" Egwene said, stopping in the hallway and looking at Nynaeve. "Do I really have you, Nynaeve?"

ðə fɔɹmɝ wɪzdəm stɑp bɪsaɪd hɝ. "ʌv kɔɹs jə du. doʊn bi sɪli"

The former Wisdom stopped beside her. "Of course you do. Don't be silly"

"æn haʊ wɪl ɪt sim," ɛɡwin æskt, "ɪf ðoʊz u noʊ mi bɛs fjuz maɪ əθɔɹəɾi? maɪɾ ɪt sim tə ði ʌðɝz ðət ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ hɛv də nɑt noʊ? səm wiknəs ðəɾ oʊnli maɪ fɹɛnz əv sin?"

"And how will it seem," Egwene asked, "if those who know me best fuse my authority? Might it seem to the others that there is something hev do not know? Some weakness that only my friends have seen?"

nɪneɪiv fɹoʊz. sʌɾənli, hɝ ɑnəsti mɛltəɾ ɪndə səspɪʃən, hɝ aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ. "ðɪs wɑzn əbaʊɾ æskɪŋ mi fəɹ ædvaɪs əɾ ɔl, wɑz ɪt?"

Nynaeve froze. Suddenly, her honesty melted into suspicion, her eyes narrowing. "This wasn't about asking me for advice at all, was it?"

"ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wɑz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "oʊnli ə ful wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ði ædvaɪs ə ðoʊz u səpɔɹt hɝ.

"Of course it was," Egwene said. "Only a fool would ignore the advice of those who support her.

bʌt haʊ dɪɾ ɪt fil fəɹ ju, ðoʊz fɝst wiks wən jə bɪkeɪm wɪzdəm? wən ɔl ðə wɪmən jə wɝ səpoʊz tə bi liɾɪŋ lʊkt ət jə oʊnli əz ðə ɡɝl ðeɪ hæd noʊn?"

But how did it feel for you, those first weeks when you became Wisdom? When all the women you were supposed to be leading looked at you only as the girl they had known?"

"tɛɹəbəl," nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli.

"jɛs. kəz aɪd bɪkʌm sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ. ɪt wɑzn mi ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ɪt wɑz maɪ steɪʃən."

"Yes. Because I'd become something more. It wasn't me any longer, it was my station."

ɛɡwin mɛt ði oʊldɝ wʊmənz aɪz, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛm, ən ən ʌndɝstændɪŋ pæs bɪtwin ðɛm.

Egwene met the older woman's eyes, holding them, and an understanding passed between them.

"laɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ju kɑt mi kwaɪt saʊnli, dɪdn ju?"

"Light," Nynaeve said. "You caught me quite soundly, didn't you?"

"aɪ nid ju, nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd. Not just because you're refreshingly untainted by Tower politics, and not just because you're one of the few who knew Rand before this all began. But because I need people I can trust implicitly. If you can be one of those."

"jul əv mi nilɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "kɪsɪŋ jəɹ ɹɪŋ."

"jɛs."

nɪneɪiv hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

əl tʃɹaɪ." ðən jə maɪt bɪɡɪn baɪ kɔlɪŋ mi mʌðɝ." ɛɡwin hɛld ʌp ə fɪŋɡɝ tə kʌɾ ɔf nɪneɪivz əbdʒɛkʃən. "tə ɹimaɪn jɝsɛlf, nɪneɪiv. ɪt nidn bi pɝmənənt, ət lis nɑɾ ɪn pɹaɪvət. bʌt jə mʌs bɪɡɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə mi əz aɪ æmɪɝlɪn."

I'll try." Then you might begin by calling me Mother." Egwene held up a finger to cut off Nynaeve's objection. "To remind yourself, Nynaeve. It needn't be permanent, at least not in private. But you must begin thinking of me as I Amyrlin."

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ɔl ɹaɪt. juv pɹɪk mi wɪð ɪnʌf θɔɹnz. aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi fil əz ɪf aɪv bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɪndsæɾɝz dʒɹæft ɔl deɪ." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æɾəd, "mʌðɝ." ʃi ɔlmoʊst sim tə tʃoʊk ɑn ðə wɝd.

"All right, all right. You've pricked me with enough thorns. I already feel as if I've been drinking windsatter's draught all day." She hesitated, then added, "Mother." She almost seemed to choke on the word.

ɛɡwin smaɪld ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋli.

Egwene smiled encouragingly.

"aɪ woʊn tʃɹit jə ðə weɪ wɪmən dɪd mi æftɝ aɪ wɑz fɝs neɪmd wɪzdəm," nɪneɪiv pɹɑməst.

"I won't treat you the way women did me after I was first named Wisdom," Nynaeve promised.

"Light! Odd to be able to feel as they did Well, they were still fools. I'll do better; you'll see it.

mʌðɝ."

Mother."

ɪt saʊndəɾ ə lɪɾəl lɛs fɔɹs ðət taɪm. ɛɡwin bɹɔɾənd əɹ smaɪl. ðəɹ wɝ fju weɪz tə moʊɾəveɪt nɪneɪiv bɛɾɝ ðən ə kɑmpətɪʃən.

It sounded a little less forced that time. Egwene broadened her smile. There were few ways to motivate Nynaeve better than a competition.

I wonder if she'll ever be able to say that without sounding awkward, Egwene thought. Well, so long as she's trying. "An excellent suggestion." She joined Nynaeve. Upon arriving in the Hall, however, they found it empty. Egwene folded her arms, looking around.

"meɪbi ʃi wɛn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌs," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

ɪleɪn pɑpt ɪndə ðə ɹum. ʃi wɔɹ ə ɹiɡəl waɪt ɡaʊn, spɑɹklɪŋ wɪð daɪmənz. əz sun əz ʃi sɔ ɛɡwin, ʃi smaɪl bɹɔdli, ɹʌʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ən teɪkɪŋ əɹ hænz. "ju dɪɾ ɪt, ɛɡwin! wɝ hoʊl əɡɛn!"

Elayne popped into the room. She wore a regal white gown, sparkling with diamonds. As soon as she saw Egwene, she smiled broadly, rushing over and taking her hands. "You did it, Egwene! We're whole again!"

ɛɡwin smaɪld. "jɛs, ðoʊ ðə taʊɝ ɪz stɪl ɪnʒɝd. ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ tə du."

"ju saʊn laɪk nɪneɪiv." ɪleɪn ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv, smaɪlɪŋ.

"Oh, don't be so silly." Elayne walked over and gave Nynaeve a friendly hug. "I'm glad you're here. I'd worried that you wouldn't come, and Egwene would have to hunt you down and pull your toes off one at a time."

"The Amyrlin," Nynaeve said, "has much better things to do. Isn't that right, Mother?"

ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd, lʊkɪŋ əmeɪzd. ʃi ɡɑɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ ɪn əɹ aɪ, ən hɪɾ ə smaɪl. ʃi əsum ðət nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ə tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ. bʌt, ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɡwin nu ðət wʊdn əv wɝkt wɪð nɪneɪiv; ɪt wəd bi laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə jæŋk ə bɝ aʊɾ ə jəɹ skɪn wən ɪts spaɪnz hæd ɡɔn ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ.

Elayne started, looking amazed. She got a glimmer in her eye, and hid a smile. She assumed that Nynaeve had been given a tongue-lashing. But, of course, Egwene knew that wouldn't have worked with Nynaeve; it would be like trying to yank a burr out of your skin when its spines had gone in the wrong way.

"ɪleɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡoʊ, bɪfɔɹ wi ɹɪtɝnd?"

"When you first came here, we were gone. Did you go somewhere looking for us?"

ɪleɪn sim pɝplɛkst. "aɪ tʃænəld ɪndə maɪ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wɛn tə slip, ən jə wɝ hɪɹ wən aɪ əpɪɹd."

"ðɛn u sɛɾ ɔf ðə wɔɹdz?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

tʃɹʌbəld, ɛɡwin ɹisɛt ðə wɔɹdz ən ðən - θɪŋkɪŋ kɛɹfəli - ʃi woʊv ən ɪnvɝɾɪd wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ bʌɾ ɔltɝɾ ɪt tə əlaʊ ə lɪɾəl bɪɾ ə saʊn θɹu. wɪð ənʌðɝ wiv, ʃi pɹədʒɛktəd ðət lɪɾəl bɪt fɑɹ aʊɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Troubled, Egwene reset the wards and then - thinking carefully - she wove an inverted ward against eavesdropping but altered it to allow a little bit of sound through. With another weave, she projected that little bit far out around them.

sʌmwʌn u ɡɹu nɪɹ wəd hɪɹ əm əz ɪf wɪspɝɪŋ. ðeɪɾ ɛdʒ kloʊsɝ, bʌt ðə saʊnd wəd ɹɪmeɪn ə wɪspɝ. pɝhæps ðət wəd dʒɹɔ ðɛm kloʊsɝ, ɪntʃ baɪ ɪntʃ, əz ðeɪ stʃɹeɪn tə hɪɹ.

Someone who grew near would hear them as if whispering. They'd edge closer, but the sound would remain a whisper. Perhaps that would draw them closer, inch by inch, as they strained to hear.

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɑtʃt əɹ meɪk ðə wivz, ɪleɪn lʊkɪŋ ɔd, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd θɔtfəli tə hɝsɛlf.

nɪneɪiv lʊk fɹəm wʌn θɹoʊn tə ənʌðɝ, ɑbviəsli dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. meɪbi ðət wɑz waɪ ʃid ɹɪzɪstɪd ðiz miɾɪŋz fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ; ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn hæd ɹɪzən soʊ fɑɹ.

Nynaeve looked from one throne to another, obviously dissatisfied. Maybe that was why she'd resisted these meetings for so long; Egwene and Elayne had risen so far.

ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ səm hʌni tə teɪk əweɪ ðə bɪɾɝnəs. "nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪd laɪk ɪt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪf jə kəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ ən titʃ mɔɹ ə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn jəɹ nu mɛθəɾ ə hilɪŋ.

It was time for some honey to take away the bitterness. "Nynaeve," Egwene said. "I'd like it very much if you could return to the Tower and teach more of the sisters in your new method of Healing.

mɛni ɑɹ lɝnɪŋ ɪt, bʌt ðeɪ kəd juz mɔɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz u ɑɹ ɹɪlʌktən tə əbændən ði oʊld weɪz."

"Stubborn goats," Nynaeve said. "Show them cherries and they'll still eat the rotten apples, if they've been doing it long enough. I'm not sure it would be prudent for me to come, though. Er, Mother."

ɹænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "sʌmwʌn əz tə kip ən aɪ ɑn hɪm. sʌmwʌn ʌðɝ ðən kædzueɪn, ət list." hɝ lɪps tɝn daʊn ət ðət wʊmənz neɪm. "hiz tʃeɪnʒd ɹisənli."

Rand," Nynaeve said. "Someone has to keep an eye on him. Someone other than Cadsuane, at least." Her lips turned down at that woman's name. "He's changed recently."

tʃeɪnʒd?" ɪleɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ kənsɝnd. "wʌt dʒju min?"

Changed?" Elayne said, sounding concerned. "What do you mean?"

hæv jə sin ɪm ɹisənli?" ɛɡwin æskt.

Have you seen him recently?" Egwene asked.

noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli. tu kwɪkli. ɪt wɑz əndaʊɾɪdli ðə tʃɹuθ- - ɪleɪn wʊdn laɪ tə hɝ - bʌt ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd. ɛɡwin hæd səspɛktəɾ ɪt fəɹ ə taɪm. kəd ʃi hæv bɑndəd hɪm?

No," Elayne said immediately. Too quickly. It was undoubtedly the truth- - Elayne wouldn't lie to her - but there were things she was hiding about Rand. Egwene had suspected it for a time. Could she have bonded him?

"hi hæz tʃeɪnʒd," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "He has changed," Nynaeve said. "And it's a very good thing. Mother . . . you don't know how bad he grew. There were times when T was terrified of him. Now ... that's gone. He's the same person -  he even talks the same way as before. Quietly, without anger. Before it was like the quiet of a knife being drawn, and now it's like the quiet of a breeze."

"hiz əweɪkənd," ɪleɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. "hiz wɔɹm naʊ."

"He's awakened," Elayne said suddenly. "He's warm now."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. "wʌt dʌz ðət min?"

Egwene frowned. "What does that mean?"

"aɪ . . . æktʃəli , aɪ doʊnt noʊ." ɪleɪn blʌʃt. "ɪt keɪm aʊt. sɑɹi."

"I . . . Actually, I don't know." Elayne blushed. "It came out. Sorry."

jɛs, ʃid bɑndəd hɪm. wɛl, ðət kəd bi jusfəl. waɪ dɪdnt ʃi wɪʃ tə spik ʌv ɪt? ɛɡwin wəɾ əv tə tɔk tə hɝ əloʊn sʌmtaɪm.

Yes, she'd bonded him. Well, that could be useful. Why didn't she wish to speak of it? Egwene would have to talk to her alone sometime.

nɪneɪiv wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ɪleɪn wɪð nɛɹoʊɾ aɪz. hæd ʃi noʊɾəst əz wɛl? hɝ aɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪnz tʃɛst, ðən daʊn əɾ əɹ bɛli.

Nynaeve was studying Elayne with narrowed eyes. Had she noticed as well? Her eyes flickered toward Elayne's chest, then down at her belly.

"jɔɹ pɹɛɡnənt!" nɪneɪiv əkjuz sʌɾənli, pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪn.

"You're pregnant!" Nynaeve accused suddenly, pointing at Elayne.

ði ændɔɝən kwin blʌʃt. ðət wɑz ɹaɪt, nɪneɪiv wʊdnt noʊ ʌv ðə pɹɛɡnənsi, ðoʊ ɛɡwin hæd hɝd fɹəm eɪvinhə.

The Andoran queen blushed. That was right, Nynaeve wouldn't know of the pregnancy, though Egwene had heard from Aviendha.

"laɪt!" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk aɪd lɛt ɹænd aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ðæt. wən dɪɾ ɪt hæpən?"

"Light!" Nynaeve said. "I didn't think I'd let Rand out of my sight long enough for that. When did it happen?"

ɪleɪn blʌʃt. "noʊbɑdi sɛd ðəɾ i - "

Elayne blushed. "Nobody said that he - "

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə flæt stɛɹ, ən ðə kwin blʌʃt fɝðɝ. boʊθ nu nɪneɪivz filɪŋz əbaʊt pɹəpɹaɪəɾi ɪn ðiz mæɾɝz - ænd, ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɛɡwin əɡɹid. bʌɾ ɪleɪnz pɹaɪvət laɪf wɑz nʌn ə hɝ bɪznəs.

Nynaeve gave Elayne a flat stare, and the Queen blushed further. Both knew Nynaeve's feelings about propriety in these matters - and, in truth, Egwene agreed. But Elayne's private life was none of her business.

"aɪm hæpi fəɹ ju, ɪleɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn fəɹ ɹænd. aɪm nɑt sɝɾən wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ə ðə taɪmɪŋ. jə ʃəd noʊ ðət ɹænd ɪz plænɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ silz əpɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, ən ɪn soʊ duɪŋ, ɹɪsk ɹilisɪŋ ɪm əpɑn ðə wɝld."

"I'm happy for you, Elayne," Egwene said. "And for Rand. I'm not certain what I think of the timing. You should know that Rand is planning to break the remaining seals upon the Dark One's prison, and in so doing, risk releasing him upon the world."

ɪleɪn pɝst əɹ lɪps. "wɛl, ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli θɹi silz lɛft, ən ðəɹ kɹʌmbəlɪŋ."

Elayne pursed her lips. "Well, there are only three seals left, and they're crumbling."

"soʊ wʌɾ ɪf hiz ɹʌnɪŋ ðət ɹɪsk?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl bi fɹid wən ðə faɪnəl sil kɹʌmbəlz; bɛst ɪf ɪt hæpənz wən ɹænd ɪz ðəɹ tə bæɾəl hɪm."

"So what if he is running that risk?" Nynaeve said. "The Dark One will be freed when the final seal crumbles; best if it happens when Rand is there to battle him."

"jɛs, bʌt ðə silz? ðæts fulhɑɹɾi. ʃʊɹli ɹænd kən feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən dɪfit hɪm, ən sil ɪm əweɪ wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ðət ɹɪsk."

"Yes, but the seals? That's foolhardy. Surely Rand can face the Dark One, and defeat him, and seal him away without taking that risk."

"meɪbi jəɹ ɹaɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"Maybe you're right," Nynaeve said.

ɪleɪn lʊk tʃɹʌbəld.

Elayne looked troubled.

ðɪs wɑz ə mɔɹ lukwɔɹm ɹɪsɛpʃən ðən ɛɡwin hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. ʃid θɔt ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd ɹɪzɪs hɝ, waɪl nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wəɾ ɪmiɾiətli si ðə deɪnʒɝ.

This was a more lukewarm reception than Egwene had expected. She'd thought that the Wise Ones would resist her, while Nynaeve and Elayne would immediately see the danger.

nɪneɪiv əz bɪn ɝaʊn ɪm tu mʌtʃ, ɛɡwin θɔt. ʃi wɑz laɪkli kɑɾ ʌp baɪ hɪz tɑvɝən neɪtʃɝ. ðə pæɾɝn bɛn ɝaʊn hɪm. ðoʊz nɪɹ ɪm wəd bɪɡɪn tə si θɪŋz ɪz weɪ, wəd wɝk - ʌnkɑnʃəsli - tə si hɪz wɪl dʌn.

Nynaeve has been around him too much, Egwene thought. She was likely caught up by his ta'veren nature. The Pattern bent around him. Those near him would begin to see things his way, would work - unconsciously - to see his will done.

ðət hæd tə bi ði ɛkspləneɪʃən. nɔɹməli, nɪneɪiv wɑz soʊ lɛvlhɛɾɪd əbaʊt ðiz sɔɹts ə θɪŋz. əɹ . . . wɛl, nɪneɪiv wɑzn ɪɡzækli lɛvlhɛɾɪd, ɹɪli. bʌt dʒɛnɝəli dɪd si ðə ɹaɪt weɪ θɪŋz niɾəd tə bi dʌn, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðət ɹaɪt weɪ dɪdn ɪnvɑlv əɹ biɪŋ ɹɔŋ.

That had to be the explanation. Normally, Nynaeve was so levelheaded about these sorts of things. Or . . . well, Nynaeve wasn't exactly levelheaded, really. But generally did see the right way things needed to be done, so long as that right way didn't involve her being wrong.

"aɪ nid boʊθ ə jə tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪleɪn, aɪ noʊ wʌt jəɹ gɑnə seɪ - ən jɛs, aɪ ɹilaɪz ðət jə ɑɹ kwin, ən ðəɾ ændɝz nidz mʌs bi mɛt. bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz jə hævən teɪkən ði oʊðz, ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl θɪŋk jə ʌndɪzɝvɪŋ."

"I need both of you to return to the Tower," Egwene said. "Elayne, I know what you're going to say - and yes, I realize that you are Queen, and that Andor's needs must be met. But so long as you haven't taken the oaths, other Aes Sedai will think you undeserving."

"ʃiz ɹaɪt, ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ju nidn vɪzət fəɹ lɔŋ -  ɪnʌf taɪm tə bi ɹeɪz fɔɹməli tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən bi æksɛptɪɾ ɪndə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. ðə noʊbəlz ʌv ændɝ woʊnt noʊ ðə dɪfɝəns, bʌɾ ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl."

"She's right, Elayne," Nynaeve said. "You needn't visit for long -  enough time to be raised formally to an Aes Sedai and be accepted into the Green Ajah. The nobles of Andor won't know the difference, but other Aes Sedai will."

"tʃɹu," ɪleɪn sɛd. "bʌt ðə taɪmɪŋ ɪz . . . ɑkwɝd. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ wɑnə ɹɪsk swɛɹɪŋ ði oʊðz waɪl pɹɛɡnənt. ɪt maɪt hɑɹm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən."

"True," Elayne said. "But the timing is . . . awkward. I don't know if I want to risk swearing the oaths while pregnant. It might harm the children."

ðət ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv pɔz.

That gave Nynaeve pause.

"ju meɪ hæv ə pɔɪnt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ wɪl əv sʌmwʌn lʊk ɪndə wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ði oʊðz ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs ɪn pɹɛɡnənsi. bʌt nɪneɪiv, aɪ wɑn jə bæk hɪɹ fəɹ sɝɾən."

"You may have a point," Egwene said. "I will have someone look into whether or not the oaths are dangerous in pregnancy. But Nynaeve, I want you back here for certain."

"ɪt wɪl liv ɹænd kəmplitli ənətɛndɪd, mʌðɝ."

"It will leave Rand completely unattended, Mother."

"aɪm əfɹeɪɾ ɪts ɪmpɑsəbəl tə əvɔɪd." ɛɡwin mɛt nɪneɪivz aɪz. "aɪ woʊn əv jə əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹi ʌv ði oʊðz. noʊ, kloʊs jəɹ maʊθ - aɪ noʊ jə tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊl tə ði oʊðz. bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ɑɹ fɹi ʌv ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɪtsɛlf, ʌðɝz wɪl wʌndɝ ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi fɹi əz wɛl."

"I'm afraid it is impossible to avoid." Egwene met Nynaeve's eyes. "I won't have you as an Aes Sedai free of the oaths. No, close your mouth - I know you try to hold to the oaths. But so long as you are free of the Oath Rod itself, others will wonder if they could be free as well."

"jɛs," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz."

"Yes," Nynaeve said. "I suppose."

"soʊ jəl ɹɪtɝn?"

"So you will return?"

nɪneɪiv klɛntʃt əɹ dʒɔ, ən sim tə bi faɪɾɪŋ ən ɪntɝnəl bæɾəl. jɛs, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd.

Nynaeve clenched her jaw, and seemed to be fighting an internal battle. Yes, Mother," she said.

ɪleɪn oʊpən əɹ aɪz waɪɾɝ ɪn ʃɑk.

Elayne opened her eyes wider in shock.

"ðɪs ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ daʊt ðəɹ ɪz ɛniθɪŋ jə əloʊn kəd də tə stɑp ɹænd naʊ. wi nid tə ɡæðɝ ælaɪz fəɹ ə junəfaɪd fɹʌnt."

"This is important, Nynaeve," Egwene said. "I doubt there is anything you alone could do to stop Rand now. We need to gather allies for a unified front."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"All right," Nynaeve said.

"wʌt wɝiz mi ɪz ðə tɛstɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðə sɪɾɝz əv bɪɡʌn tə ɑɹɡju ðət - waɪl ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt tə ɹeɪz jə ən ði ʌðɝz ɪn ɛɡzaɪl-ju ʃəd stɪl əv tə ɡoʊ θɹu ðə tɛstɪŋ, naʊ ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz ɹiunəfaɪd. ðeɪ meɪk vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ɑɹɡjəməns. pɝhæps aɪ kən ɑɹɡju ðət jəɹ dɪfəkəl tʃælənʒɪz ɹisənli ʃəɾ ɝn jə ən ɪɡzɛmpʃən. wi doʊn əv taɪm tə titʃ jə tu ɔl ə ðə wivz jud nid."

"What worries me is the testing," Egwene said. "The Sitters have begun to argue that - while it was all right to raise you and the others in exile-you should still have to go through the testing, now that the White Tower is reunified. They make very good arguments. Perhaps I can argue that your difficult challenges recently should earn you an exemption. We don't have time to teach you two all of the weaves you'd need."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd. nɪneɪiv ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪl də ðə tɛstɪŋ. ɪf aɪm gɑnə kʌm bæk, ðən aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl də ðɪs pɹɑpɝli."

Elayne nodded. Nynaeve shrugged. "I'll do the testing. If I'm going to come back, then I might as well do this properly."

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "nɪneɪiv, ðiz ɑɹ vɛɹi kɑmplɛks wivz aɪ hævən hæd taɪm tə mɛmɝaɪz ɔl ə ðɛm; aɪ swɛɹ ðət mɛni ɑɹ nid-lɛsli ɔɹneɪt sɪmpli tə bi dɪfəkəlt." ɛɡwin hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə tɛstɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ən dɪdnt nid tə. ðə lɔ wɑz spəsɪfɪk. v biɪŋ meɪɾ æmɪɝlɪn, ʃi hæd bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ. θɪŋz wɝn əz klɪɹ ɪn ɹɪɡɑɹdz tə nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝz ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd ɹeɪzd.

Egwene blinked in surprise. "Nynaeve, these are very complex weaves I haven't had time to memorize all of them; I swear that many are need-lessly ornate simply to be difficult." Egwene had no intention of going through the testing herself, and didn't need to. The law was specific. Bv being made Amyrlin, she had become Aes Sedai. Things weren't as clear in regards to Nynaeve and the others that Egwene had raised.

nɪneɪiv ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn. "ðə hʌnʒɹəd tɛstɪŋ wivz ɑɹən soʊ bæɾ aɪ kəd ʃoʊ ðɛm tə jə ɹaɪt hɪɹ, ɪf jə wɑntəd mi tə."

Nynaeve shrugged again. "The hundred testing weaves aren't so bad I could show them to you right here, if you wanted me to."

"wɛn əv jə hæd taɪm tə lɝn ðoʊz?" ɪleɪn ɪkskleɪmd.

"When have you had time to learn those?" Elayne exclaimed.

"aɪ hævən spɛn ðə læs fju mʌnθs munɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən dʒɹimɪŋ ə ɹænd ælθɹ."

"I haven't spent the last few months mooning about and dreaming of Rand al'Thor."

"sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ ɪz nɑt 'munɪŋ əbaʊt'!"

"Securing the throne of Andor is not 'mooning about'!"

"nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin kʌɾ ɪn, "ɪf jə tʃɹuli hæv ðə wivz mɛmɝaɪzd, ðən biɪŋ ɹeɪz pɹɑpɝli wəd hɛlp mi ə ɡɹeɪt dil. ɪt wəd lʊk lɛs laɪk aɪm feɪvɝɪŋ maɪ fɹɛnz."

"Nynaeve," Egwene cut in, "if you truly have the weaves memorized, then being raised properly would help me a great deal. It would look less like I'm favoring my friends."

"ðə tɛstɪŋ ɪz səpoʊz tə bi deɪnʒɝəs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ juv ðə wivz ɪn hænd?"

"The testing is supposed to be dangerous," Elayne said. "Are you sure you have the weaves in hand?"

"aɪl bi faɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"I'll be fine," Nynaeve said.

"ɛksələnt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪl ɪkspɛk jə hɪɹ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

"Excellent," Egwene said. "I'll expect you here in the morning."

"soʊ sun!" nɪneɪiv sɛd, əɡæst.

"So soon!" Nynaeve said, aghast.

"ðə sunɝ jə kən hoʊl ðəɾ oʊθ ɹɑd, ðə sunɝ əl bi eɪbəl tə stɑp wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ju.

"The sooner you can hold that Oath Rod, the sooner I'll be able to stop worrying about you.

ɪleɪn, wɪl stɪl əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ju."

Elayne, we'll still have to do something about you."

"ðə pɹɛɡnənsi," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɪts ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ wɪð maɪ əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl. ðæts ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ - aɪ kəd ɡɛt hɪɹ, θæŋkfəli - bʌɾ ɪts stɪl ə pɹɑbləm. ɪkspleɪn tə ðə hɔl ɪt wəd bi tu deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ mi - ən fəɹ ðə beɪbz - tə ʌndɝɡoʊ ðə tɛstɪŋ waɪl əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl kənsɪstənli."

"The pregnancy," Elayne said. "It's interfering with my ability to channel. That's getting better - I could get here, thankfully - but it's still a problem. Explain to the Hall it would be too dangerous for me - and for the babes - to undergo the testing while unable to channel consistently."

"ðeɪ maɪt sədʒɛs jə weɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"They might suggest you wait," Nynaeve said.

"æn lɛf mi ɹʌn ɝaʊnd wɪθaʊt ði oʊðz?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðoʊ aɪ wəd laɪk tə noʊ ɪf ɛniwʌnz teɪkən ði oʊðz waɪl pɹɛɡnən bɪfɔɹ, dʒʌs tə bi ʃʊɹ."

"And lef me run around without the oaths?" Elayne said. "Though I would like to know if anyone's taken the oaths while pregnant before, just to be sure."

"aɪl faɪnd wʌɾ aɪ kæn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "əntɪl ðɛn, aɪ hæv ənʌðɝ tæsk fəɹ ju."

"I'll find what I can," Egwene said. "Until then, I have another task for you."

"aɪ æm ɹæðɝ bɪzi wɪð ɹulɪŋ ændɝ, mʌðɝ."

"I am rather busy with ruling Andor, Mother."

"aɪ noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi ɛls aɪ kən æsk. aɪ nid mɔɹ dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil.'

"I know," Egwene said. "Unfortunately, there's nobody else I can ask. I need more dream ter'angreal.'

"aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə mænədʒ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "əsumɪŋ aɪ kən stɑɹt tʃænəlɪŋ ɹɪlaɪəbli."

"I might be able to manage," Elayne said. "Assuming I can start channeling reliably."

"wʌt hæpən tə ðə dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil jə hæd?" nɪneɪiv æskt ɛɡwin.

"What happened to the dream ter'angreal you had?" Nynaeve asked Egwene.

"stoʊlən," ɛɡwin sɛd. "baɪ ʃɛɹiəm - hu, baɪ ðə weɪ, wɑz blæk ədʒɑ"

"Stolen," Egwene said. "By Sheriam - who, by the way, was Black Ajah"

They turned a corner into a street where a group of nervous Defenders - -wearing black coats and silvery breastplates, black and gold sleeves puffing out at the sides - stood in a line.
