ðə sɪɾi bɪɑn əm lʊk feɪnli . . . blændɝ ðən ɪt ʃʊd. wɑʃt aʊt. ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz wɝ ə laɪɾɝ ʃeɪɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪ, ðə wɔlz ə ðə bɪldɪŋz ə feɪntɝ bɹaʊn əɹ ɡɹeɪ ðən ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv bɪn.

The city beyond them looked faintly . . . blander than it should. Washed out. The paving stones were a lighter shade of gray, the walls of the buildings a fainter brown or gray than they should have been.

"ju hæv mɛn ɪnsaɪd sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ wundəd?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"You have men inside searching for wounded?" Nynaeve asked.

wʌn ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wiv bɪn kipɪŋ pipəl aʊt, ɝ, leɪɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪts nɑt seɪf."

One of the Defenders shook his head. "We've been keeping people out, er, Lady Aes Sedai. It's not safe."

moʊs tɛɹənz stɪl wɝn əkʌstəm tə ʃoʊɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪspɛkt. əntɪl ɹisənli, tʃænəlɪŋ hæd bɪn aʊtlɔɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi.

Most Tairens still weren't accustomed to showing Aes Sedai respect. Until recently, channeling had been outlawed in the city.

"sɛn jəɹ mɛn ɹoʊ sɝtʃ," nɪneɪiv sɛd fɝmli. "ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪl bi əpsɛɾ ɪf jəɹ təmɪɾəti kɑsts laɪvz. stɑɹɾ ət ðə pɝɪməɾɝ. sɛn fəɹ mi ɪf jə faɪn ɛniwʌn aɪ kən hɛlp."

"Send your men ro search," Nynaeve said firmly. "The Lord Dragon ill be upset if your timidity costs lives. Start at the perimeter. Send for me if you find anyone I can help."

ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn muvd ɔf. nɪneɪiv tɝn tə nf, ən i nɑɾəd, ʃi tɝn ən tʊk ə stɛp ɪndə ði əfɛktəd sɛkʃən ə taʊn. wən əɹ fʊt hɪt ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊn, ðə stoʊn tɝn tə dʌst. hɝ fud sæŋk θɹu ðə ʃæɾɝd peɪvɪŋ stoʊn ən hɪt pækt ɝθ.

The guardsmen moved off. Nynaeve turned to Naeff, and he nodded, She turned and took a step into the affected section of town. When her foot hit the paving stone, the stone turned to dust. Her food sank through the shattered paving stone and hit packed earth.

ʃi lʊk daʊn, filɪŋ ə tʃɪl. ʃi kəntɪnjud fɔɹwɝd, ən ðə stoʊnz fɛl tə paʊɾɝ əz ʃi tʌtʃt ðɛm. ʃi ən nf meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ tə ə nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋ, livɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪl ə paʊɾɝd ɹɑk bɪhaɪnd. ðə bɪldɪŋ wɑz ən ɪn wɪð naɪs bælkəniz ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, dɛləkəɾ aɪɝnwɝk pæɾɝnz ɑn ðə ɡlæs wɪndoʊz, ən ə dɑɹkli steɪn pɔɹtʃ. ðə dɔɹ wɑz oʊpən, ən əz ʃi lɪftəɾ əɹ fʊɾ ʌp tə stɛp ɑntu ðə loʊ pɔɹtʃ, ðə bɔɹdz ɔlsoʊ tɝn tə paʊɾɝ. ʃi fɹoʊz, lʊkɪŋ daʊn. nf stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɝ, ðən nɛl daʊn, pɪntʃɪŋ ðə dʌs bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz.

She looked down, feeling a chill. She continued forward, and the stones fell to powder as she touched them. She and Naeff made their way to a nearby building, leaving a trail of powdered rock behind. The building was an inn with nice balconies on the second floor, delicate ironwork patterns on the glass windows, and a darkly stained porch. The door was open, and as she lifted her foot up to step onto the low porch, the boards also turned to powder. She froze, looking down. Naeff stepped up beside her, then knelt down, pinching the dust between his fingers.

"ɪts sɑft," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, "æz faɪn ə paʊɾɝ əz aɪv ɛvɝ tʌtʃt."

"It's soft," he said quietly, "as fine a powder as I've ever touched."

ði ɛɹ smɛld ənnətʃɝəli fɹɛʃ, kəntʃɹæstɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒli wɪð ðə saɪlən stʃɹit. nɪneɪiv tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən wɛn ɪndə ði ɪn. ʃi hæd tə pʊʃ fɔɹwɝd, wɔkɪŋ wɪð ðə wʊɾən flɔɹ əɾ əɹ niz, ðə bɔɹdz dɪsɪntəɡɹeɪɾɪŋ əz ʃi tʌtʃt ðɛm.

The air smelled unnaturally fresh, contrasting strangely with the silent street. Nynaeve took a deep breath, then went into the inn. She had to push forward, walking with the wooden floor at her knees, the boards disintegrating as she touched them.

ði ɪnsaɪd wɑz dɪm. ðə stænd-læmps noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɝnd. pipəl sæɾ əbaʊt ðə ɹum, fɹoʊzən ɪn mɪdmoʊʃən. moʊst wɝ noʊbəlz wɪð faɪn kloʊðɪŋ, ðə mɛn wɛɹɪŋ bɪɹdz ɔɪl tə ə pɔɪnt. wʌn sæɾ əɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ tɔl teɪbəl wɪð lɔŋ-lɛɡəd tʃɛɹz. hi hæɾ ə mʌɡ ʌv mɔɹnɪŋ eɪl hæfweɪ tə hɪz lɪps. hi wɑz moʊʃənləs, hɪz maʊθ oʊpən tə æksɛp ðə dʒɹɪŋk.

The inside was dim. The stand-lamps no longer burned. People sat about the room, frozen in midmotion. Most were nobles with fine clothing, the men wearing beards oiled to a point. One sat at a nearby tall table with long-legged chairs. He had a mug of morning ale halfway to his lips. He was motionless, his mouth open to accept the drink.

nfs feɪs wɑz ɡɹɪm, ɔlðoʊ lɪɾəl sim tə sɝpɹaɪz əɹ ənsɛɾəl æʃəmən. əz i tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp fɔɹwɝd, nɪneɪiv lʌnʒd ən ɡɹæbd ɪz ɑɹm. hi fɹaʊn ət hɝ, ən ʃi pɔɪntəd daʊn. ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm - bɛɹli vɪzəbəl bɪniθ ðə stɪl-hoʊl flɔɹbɔɹdz ɹaɪɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm- - ðə ɡɹaʊn fɛl əweɪ. hid bɪn əbaʊt tə stɛp ɪndə ði ɪnz sɛlɝ.

Naeff's face was grim, although little seemed to surprise or unsettle Asha'man. As he took another step forward, Nynaeve lunged and grabbed his arm. He frowned at her, and she pointed down. Right in front of him - barely visible beneath the still-whole floorboards right ahead of them- - the ground fell away. He'd been about to step into the inn's cellar.

laɪt," nf sɛd, stɛpɪŋ bæk. hi nɛl daʊn, ðən tæp ðə bɔɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ɪt fɛl tə dʌst, ʃaʊɝɪŋ daʊn ɪndə ðə dɑɹk sɛlɝ bɪloʊ.

Light," Naeff said, stepping back. He knelt down, then tapped the board in front of him. It fell to dust, showering down into the dark cellar below.

nɪneɪiv woʊv spɪɹət, ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ tə dɛlv ðə mæn sɪɾɪŋ ət ðə tʃɛɹ hɝ. nɔɹməli ʃi wəd tʌtʃ sʌmwʌn tə dɛlv ðɛm, bʌt ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ðɪs taɪm. ɪt wəd wɝk wɪθaʊt tʌtʃ, bʌt wəd nɑt bi əz ɪfɛktɪv fəɹ hilɪŋ.

Nynaeve wove Spirit, Air and Water to Delve the man sitting at the chair her. Normally she would touch someone to Delve them, but she hesitated this time. It would work without touch, but would not be as effective for Healing.

hɝ dɛlvɪŋ faʊnd nʌθɪŋ. noʊ laɪf, noʊ sɛns ðəɾ i hæɾ ɛvɝ əlaɪv. hɪz bɑɾi wɑzn ivən flɛʃ.

Her Delving found nothing. No life, no sense that he had ever alive. His body wasn't even flesh.

wɪð ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ, ʃi dɛlvd ʌðɝ pipəl ɪn ðə dɑɹkən ɹum. ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd kæɹiɪŋ bɹɛkfəs toʊɛɹi θɹi ændɔɝən mɝtʃəns. ə kɔɹpjələn ɪnkipɝ, hu mʌst əv hæd tʃɹʌbəl nævəɡeɪɾɪŋ bɪtwin ðə kloʊs-sɛt teɪbəlz. ə wʊmən ɪn ə ɹɪtʃ dʒɹə$ sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə vɛɹi bæk ə ðə ɹum, pɹɪmli ɹiɾɪŋ ə smɔl bʊk.

With a sinking feeling, she Delved other people in the darkened room. A serving maid carrying breakfast towari three Andoran merchants. A corpulent innkeeper, who must have had trouble navigating between the close-set tables. A woman in a rich dre$ sitting in the very back of the room, primly reading a small book.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ laɪf ɪn ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ðiz wɝn kɔɹpsəz; ðeɪ wɝ hʌsks. fɪŋɡɝz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, nɪneɪiv ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən bɹʌʃt ðə ʃoʊldɝ ə ðə mæn ət ðə haɪ teɪbəl. hi ɪmiɾiətli fɛl tə paʊɾɝ, dʌst ʃaʊɝɪŋ daʊnwɝɾ ɪn ə pʌf. ðə tʃɛɹ ən flɔɹbɔɹdz ʌndɝniθ dɪd nɑt dɪzɑlv.

There was no life in any of them. These weren't corpses; they were husks. Fingers trembling, Nynaeve reached out and brushed the shoulder of the man at the high table. He immediately fell to powder, dust showering downward in a puff. The chair and floorboards underneath did not dissolve.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊbɑdi hɪɹ tə seɪv," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"There is nobody here to save," Nynaeve said.

"pʊɹ pipəl," nf sɛd. "laɪt ʃɛltɝ ðɛɹ soʊlz."

"Poor people," Naeff said. "Light shelter their souls."

nɪneɪiv ɔfən hæd tʃɹʌbəl filɪŋ pɪɾi fəɹ ðə tɛɹən noʊbəlz - -ʌv ɔl ðə pipəl ʃi hæd mɛt, ðeɪ simd əmʌŋ ðə moʊst ɛɹəɡənt. bʌt noʊbɑdi dɪzɝv ðɪs. bɪsaɪdz, ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə kɑmənɝz hæd bɪn kɑɾ ɪn ðɪs bʌbəl əz wɛl.

Nynaeve often had trouble feeling pity for the Tairen nobles - -of all the people she had met, they seemed among the most arrogant. But nobody deserved this. Besides, a large number of commoners had been caught in this bubble as well.

ʃi ən nf meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ, nɪneɪivz fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən maʊntɪŋ əz ʃi tʌɡd ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. ʃi heɪɾəd filɪŋ hɛlpləs. laɪk wɪð ðə pʊɹ ɡɑɹɾ u hæd stɑɹɾəd ðə faɪɝ bæk ət ðə mænɝ haʊs ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, əɹ ðə pipəl u wɝ stʃɹʌk daʊn baɪ stʃɹeɪnʒ dɪzizəz. ðə dʌsti hʌsks ðɪs deɪ. wʌt wɑz ðə ɡʊɾ ə lɝnɪŋ tə hil ɪf ʃi kʊdn hɛlp pipəl?

She and Naeff made their way out of the building, Nynaeve's frustration mounting as she tugged on her braid. She hated feeling helpless. Like with the poor guard who had started the fire back at the manor house in Arad Doman, or the people who were struck down by strange diseases. The dusty husks this day. What was the good of learning to Heal if she couldn't help people?

ən naʊ ʃi hæd tə liv. ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɪt fɛlt laɪk ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ. ʃi tɝn tə nf. "wɪnd," ʃi sɛd.

And now she had to leave. Go back to the White Tower. It felt like running away. She turned to Naeff. "Wind," she said.

"nɪneɪiv sədaɪ?"

"Nynaeve Sedai?"

"ɡɪv ðə bɪldɪŋ ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪnd, nf," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ wɑnə si wʌt hæpənz."

"Give the building a gust of wind, Naeff," she said. "I want to see what happens."

ði æʃəmən dɪɾ əz ʃi æskt, hɪz ɪnvɪzəbəl wivz bloʊɪŋ ə dʒɛɾ ʌv ɛɹ. ði ɪntaɪɝ bɪldɪŋ bɝst, ʃæɾɝɪŋ ɪndə dʌs ðət blu əweɪ, laɪk ðə waɪt sidz ʌv ə dændəlaɪən. nf tɝn tə hɝ.

The Asha'man did as she asked, his invisible weaves blowing a jet of air. The entire building burst, shattering into dust that blew away, like the white seeds of a dandelion. Naeff turned to her.

"haʊ waɪd dɪd ðeɪ seɪ ðɪs bʌbəl wɑz?" ʃi æskt.

"How wide did they say this bubble was?" she asked.

"əbaʊt tu stʃɹits waɪɾ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz."

"About two streets wide in all directions."

"wi nid mɔɹ wɪnd," ʃi sɛd, bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə wiv. "kɹieɪɾ ə ɡʌst əz lɑɹdʒ əz jə kæn. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛniwʌn wundəɾ ɪn hɪɹ, wɪl faɪn əm ðɪs weɪ."

"We need more wind," she said, beginning a weave. "Create a gust as large as you can. If there is anyone wounded in here, we'll find them this way."

nf nɑɾəd. ðə tu ʌv əm stʃɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd, kɹieɪɾɪŋ wɪnd. ðeɪ ʃæɾɝd bɪldɪŋz, kɑzɪŋ əm tə bɝst ən fɔl. nf wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ skɪld ət ðə pɹɑsɛs ðən ʃi, bʌt nɪneɪiv wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ swɛp ðə kɹʌmbəlɪŋ bɪldɪŋz, stoʊnz ən hʌsks bɪfɔɹ əm ɪn ə dʌst stɔɹm.

Naeff nodded. The two of them strode forward, creating wind. They shattered buildings, causing them to burst and fall. Naeff was far more skilled at the process than she, but Nynaeve was stronger in the One Power. Together, they swept the crumbling buildings, stones and husks before them in a dust storm.

ɪt wɑz ɪɡzɔstɪŋ wɝk, bʌt ðeɪ kɛpt əɾ ɪt. ʃi hoʊpt - əɡɛnst ɹizən -__ðæt ʃi maɪt faɪn sʌmwʌn tə hɛlp. bɪldɪŋz fɛl bɪfɔɹ əɹ ən nf, ðə dʌs kɑɾ ɪn swɝlɪŋ ɛɹ. ðeɪ pʊʃt ðə dʌst ɪn ə sɝkəl muvɪŋ ɪnwɝd. laɪk ə wʊmən swipɪŋ ðə flɔɹ.

It was exhausting work, but they kept at it. She hoped - against reason -__that she might find someone to help. Buildings fell before her and Naeff, the dust caught in swirling air. They pushed the dust in a circle moving inward. Like a woman sweeping the floor.

ðeɪ pæs pipəl fɹoʊzən ɑn ðə stʃɹits ɪn mɪdstʃɹaɪd. ɑksən pʊlɪŋ ə kɑɹt. hɑɹt-ɹɛntʃɪŋli, səm tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪɪŋ ɪn ən æli. ɔl fɛl tə dʌst.

They passed people frozen on the streets in midstride. Oxen pulling a cart. Heart-wrenchingly, some children playing in an alley. All fell to dust.

ðeɪ faʊnd noʊbɑdi əlaɪv. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi ən nf hæd dɪzɑlvd ɔl ɛf ðə bɹoʊkən pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ən bloʊn ðə dʌst ɪndə ðə sɛntɝ. nɪneɪiv lʊkt əɾ ɪt, kɛp swɝlɪŋ ɪn pleɪs baɪ ə smɔl sɪkloʊn nf hæd woʊvən.

They found nobody alive. Eventually, she and Naeff had dissolved all f the broken part of the city and blown the dust into the center. Nynaeve looked at it, kept swirling in place by a small cyclone Naeff had woven.

kjʊɹiəs, nɪneɪiv tʃænəld ə tʌŋ ə faɪɝ ɪndə ðə sɪkloʊn, ən ðə dʌs kɑɾ əlaɪt.

Curious, Nynaeve channeled a tongue of Fire into the cyclone, and the dust caught alight.

nɪneɪiv ɡæspt; ðət dʌst wɛn ʌp laɪk dʒɹaɪd peɪpɝ θɹoʊn ɪndə ə faɪɝ, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə ɹɔɹɪŋ tɛmpəst ə fleɪmz. ʃi ən nf bækt əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ ɪn ə flæʃ. ɪt dɪdn liv ɛni æʃ bɪhaɪnd.

Nynaeve gasped; that dust went up like dried paper thrown into a fire, creating a roaring tempest of flames. She and Naeff backed away, but it was over in a flash. It didn't leave any ash behind.

ɪf wi hædnt ɡæðɝɾ ɪt, ʃi θɔt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə faɪɝ feɪɾ əweɪ, sʌmwʌn maɪɾ əv dʒɹɑpt ə kændəl ɑn ɪt. ə faɪɝ laɪk ðæt. . .

If we hadn't gathered it, she thought, watching the fire fade away, someone might have dropped a candle on it. A fire like that. . .

nf stɪld ɪz wɪnz. ðə tu ʌv əm stʊɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ən oʊpən sɝkəl ə bɛɹ ɝθ wɪð pɪɹiɑɾɪk hoʊlz fəɹ sɛlɝz. ɑn ði ɛdʒəz, bɪldɪŋz hæd bɪn slaɪst ɪntu, ɹumz oʊpən tə ði ɛɹ, səm stʃɹʌktʃɝz hævɪŋ kəlæpst. ɪt wɑz ɪɹi, tə si ðɪs hɑloʊ ɛɹiə. laɪk ə ɡaʊdʒd-aʊɾ aɪ sɑkəɾ ɪn ən ʌðɝwaɪz hɛlθi feɪs.

Naeff stilled his winds. The two of them stood in the center of an open circle of bare earth with periodic holes for cellars. On the edges, buildings had been sliced into, rooms open to the air, some structures having collapsed. It was eerie, to see this hollow area. Like a gouged-out eye socket in an otherwise healthy face.

sɛvɹəl ɡɹups ə dɪfɛndɝz stʊɾ ət ðə pɝɪməɾɝ. ʃi nɑɾəd tə nf, ən ðeɪ wɔk tə ðə lɑɹdʒəst ɡɹup. "ju dɪdn faɪn ɛniwʌn?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

Several groups of Defenders stood at the perimeter. She nodded to Naeff, and they walked to the largest group. "You didn't find anyone?" she demanded.

Nynaeve found herself nodding, then was annoyed at herself. She was taking advice from Rand alThor?

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɹən əbaʊt ɹænd naʊ. kwaɪəɾ ɪntɛnsəɾi ən kɛɹfəl wɝdz. hi wɑz ə mæn jə kəd teɪk ædvaɪs fɹəm wɪθaʊt filɪŋ i spikɪŋ daʊn tə ju. laɪk ɪz fɑðɝ, æktʃəli . nɑt ðət ʃiɾ ɛvɝ ədmɪt ðət tə iðɝ wʌn ə ðɛm.

"I will be there, Rand." She felt oddly proud. "Hold still for a moment. I won't hurt you. I promise."

hi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt dɪd nʌθɪŋ əz ʃi dɛlv hɪm. ʃi wɑz soʊ taɪɝd, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi wɑz gɑnə liv hɪm, ʃi niɾəd tə teɪk ðɪs ɑpɝtunəɾi tə hil ɪz mædnəs. ɪt simd, sʌɾənli, ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ ʃi kəd də fəɹ hɪm. ən fəɹ ðə wɝld.

ʃi dɛlvd, steɪɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə wunz əɾ ɪz saɪd, wɪtʃ wɝ pɪts ə dɑɹknəs ðət sim tə tʃɹaɪ tə sʌk ɪn əɹ ɛnɝdʒi. ʃi kɛpt əɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn ɪz maɪnd. wɛɹ wɑz ðə -  ʃi stɪfənd. ðə dɑɹknəs wɑz ɪnɔɹməs, kʌvɝɪŋ ði ɪntaɪɝɾi ʌv ɪz maɪnd. θaʊzənz əpɑn θaʊzənz ə ðə taɪni blæk θɔɹnz pɹɪkt ɪndə hɪz bɹeɪn, bʌt bɪniθ əm wɑz ə bɹɪljənt waɪt lɑsɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ. ə waɪt ɹeɪdʒjəns, laɪk lɪkwəd paʊɝ. laɪt ɡɪvən fɔɹm ən laɪf. ʃi ɡæspt. ɪt koʊɾəd itʃ ə ðə dɑɹk taɪnz, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɪndə hɪz maɪn əlɔŋsaɪd ðɛm. wʌɾ ɪt min?

She Delved, staying away from the wounds at his side, which were pits of darkness that seemed to try to suck in her energy. She kept her attention on his mind. Where was the -  She stiffened. The darkness was enormous, covering the entirety of his mind. Thousands upon thousands of the tiny black thorns pricked into his brain, but beneath them was a brilliant white lacing of something. A white radiance, like liquid Power. Light given form and life. She gasped. It coated each of the dark tines, driving into his mind alongside them. What did it mean?

ʃi dɪdn əv ɛni aɪdiə haʊ tə bɪɡɪn wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðɪs. ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni bɑɹbz. haʊ kəɾ i ivən θɪŋk wɪð ðət mʌtʃ dɑɹknəs pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz bɹeɪn? ən wʌt hæd kɹieɪɾəd ðə waɪtnəs?

ʃid hild ɹænd bɪfɔɹ, ən hædnt noʊɾəst ɪt ðɛn. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃid nɛvɝ sin ðə dɑɹknəs əntɪl ɹisənli. hɝ pɹæktəs wɪð dɛlvɪŋ wɑz laɪkli ðə ɹizən. ʃi ɹɪlʌktənli wɪθdʒɹu. "aɪm sɑɹi," ʃi sɛd. She'd Healed Rand before, and hadn't noticed it then. Of course, she'd never seen the darkness until recently. Her practice with Delving was likely the reason. She reluctantly withdrew. "I'm sorry," she said. "I can't Heal you." Many have tried on those wounds - you yourself included. They are simply unhealable. I don't think on them much, these days."

ðə klaʊdz hæd ɹɪtɝnd.

Saerin, Yukiri and Seaine - three of the sisters who had been the original hunters for the Black Ajah in the Tower - waited patiently behind her. ʌðɝz wɝ wʌns sɛd tə ɪɡzɪst, ən ɪts plɔzəbəl ðət wʌn ɹɑd kəd ɹilis jə fɹəm ði oʊðz ʌv ənʌðɝ. mɛsænə cʊɾə bɪn hoʊldɪŋ wʌn sikɹɪtli. ʃi cʊɾə teɪkən ðə θɹi oʊðz waɪl hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɹɑd, ðən sʌmhaʊ juz ði ʌðɝ tə nɪɡeɪt ðoʊz oʊðz bɪfɔɹ swɛɹɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

Others were once said to exist, and it's plausible that one rod could release you from the oaths of another. Mesaana could have been holding one secretly. She could have taken the Three Oaths while holding our rod, then somehow used the other to negate those oaths before swearing that she was not a Darkfriend."

tɛnjəwəs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "haʊ wəd ʃi hæv ɹilis hɝsɛlf wɪθaʊɾ əs noʊɪŋ? ɪt ɹikwaɪɝz tʃænəlɪŋ spɪɹət."

Tenuous," Egwene said. "How would she have released herself without us knowing? It requires channeling Spirit."

"aɪ kənsɪɾɝd ðæt," sin sɛd.

"I considered that," Seaine said.

"nɑt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ," jukɪɝi sɛd.

"Not surprising," Yukiri said.

sin aɪd hɝ, ðən kəntɪnjud. "ðɪs ɪz ðə ɹizən mɛsænə wʊɾə niɾəd ə sɛkən oʊθ ɹɑd. ʃi cʊɾə tʃænəl spɪɹəɾ ɪndə ɪt, ðən ɪnvɝɾɪd ðə wiv, livɪŋ əɹ lɪŋk tə ɪt."

Seaine eyed her, then continued. "This is the reason Mesaana would have needed a second Oath Rod. She could have channeled Spirit into it, then inverted the weave, leaving her linked to it."

ɪt simz ɪmpɹɑbəbəl," ɛɡwin sɛd.

It seems improbable," Egwene said.

"ɪmpɹɑbəbəl?" sɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪt simz ɹɪdɪkjələs. aɪ θɔt jə sɛd səm ə ðiz wɝ plɔzəbəl, jukɪɝi."

"Improbable?" Saerin replied. "It seems ridiculous. I thought you said some of these were plausible, Yukiri."

"ðɪs wʌn ɪz ðə lis laɪkli ʌv ðə θɹi," sin sɛd. "ðə sɛkən mɛθəd wəd bi iziɝ. mɛsænə cʊɾə sɛn ə lʊk-əlaɪk wɛɹɪŋ ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts. səm ənfɔɹtʃənət sɪstɝ - əɹ nɑvəs, əɹ ivən səm ʌn-tʃɹeɪnd wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl - ʌndɝ hɛvi kəmpʌlʃən. ðɪs wʊmən cʊɾə bɪn fɔɹs tə teɪk ði oʊðz ɪn mɛsænəz pleɪs. ðɛn, sɪns ðɪs pɝsən wʊdn bi ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ʃi kəd spik tʃɹuθfəli ðət ʃi wɑznt."

"This one is the least likely of the three," Seaine said. "The second method would be easier. Mesaana could have sent a look-alike wearing the Mirror of Mists. Some unfortunate sister - or novice, or even some un-trained woman who could channel - under heavy Compulsion. This woman could have been forced to take the oaths in Mesaana's place. Then, since this person wouldn't be a Darkfriend, she could speak truthfully that she wasn't."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. "ðæt wʊɾə teɪkən ə lɑɾ ə pɹipə-ɹæʃən."

Egwene nodded thoughtfully. "That would have taken a lot of prepa-ration."

"fɹʌm wʌɾ aɪv bɪn eɪbəl tə lɝn əbaʊt hɝ," sɹɪn sɛd, "mɛsən wɑz ɡʊɾ ət pɹɛpɝeɪʃən. ʃi ɪksɛld əɾ ɪt."

"From what I've been able to learn about her," Saerin said, "Mesaan was good at preparation. She excelled at it."

sɹɪnz tæsk hæd bɪn tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌtɛvɝ ʃi kəɾ əbaʊt mɛsænəz tʃɹu neɪtʃɝ. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl hɝd ðə stɔɹiz - hu dɪdnt noʊ ðə neɪmz ʌv itʃ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ən ðɛɹ moʊs tɛɹəbəl didz, baɪ hɑɹt? bʌɾ ɛɡwin pʊt lɪɾəl feɪθ ɪn stɔɹiz; ʃi wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ hɑɹdfæst, ɪf ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ ɪt.

Saerin's task had been to discover whatever she could about Mesaana's true nature. They had all heard the stories - who didn't know the names of each of the Forsaken, and their most terrible deeds, by heart? But Egwene put little faith in stories; she wanted something more hardfast, if she could get it.

"ju sɛd ðəɹ wɑz ə θɝd pɑsəbɪləɾi?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"You said there was a third possibility?" Egwene asked.

"jɛs," sin sɛd. "wi noʊ ðət səm wivz pleɪ wɪð saʊnd. vɛɹieɪʃənz ɑn voʊkəl wivz ɑɹ juz tə ɛnhæns ə vɔɪs tə pɹədʒɛk tə ə kɹaʊd, ən ɪn ðə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ - ɪndid, ðəɹ juzd ɪn ðə vɛɹiəs tʃɹɪks juz tə lɪsən ɪn ɑn wʌɾ ɪz biɪŋ sɛd nɪɹbaɪ. kɑmplɛks jusəz ə ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts kən tʃeɪnʒ ə pɝsənz vɔɪs. wɪð səm pɹæktəs, dʌsin ən aɪ wɝ eɪbəl tə fæbɹəkeɪɾ ə vɛɹieɪʃən ɑn ə wiv ðət wəɾ ɔltɝ ðə wɝdz wi spoʊk. ɪn ɪfɛkt, wi sɛd wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt ði ʌðɝ pɝsən hɝɾ ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ɪntaɪɝli."

"Yes," Seaine said. "We know that some weaves play with sound. Variations on vocal weaves are used to enhance a voice to project to a crowd, and in the ward against eavesdropping - indeed, they're used in the various tricks used to listen in on what is being said nearby. Complex uses of the Mirror of Mists can change a person's voice. With some practice, Doesine and I were able to fabricate a variation on a weave that would alter the words we spoke. In effect, we said one thing, but the other person heard another thing entirely."

"deɪnʒɝəs ɡɹaʊn tə wɔk, sin," sɹɪn sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs ɡɹʌf. "ðæɾ ɪz ðə kaɪndə wiv ðət kəd bi juz fəɹ ɪl pɝpəsəz."

"Dangerous ground to walk, Seaine," Saerin said, her voice gruff. "That is the kind of weave that could be used for ill purposes."

"aɪ kʊdn juz ɪt tə laɪ," sin sɛd. "aɪ tʃɹaɪd. ði oʊðz hoʊld - soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə wiv wɑz ðɛɹ, aɪ kʊdn spik wɝdz ðəɾ aɪ nu ənʌðɝ wəd hɪɹ əz laɪz, ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹuθ wən ðeɪ lɛf maɪ lɪps. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, ɪt wɑz ən izi wiv tə dɪvɛləp. taɪɾ ɔf ən ɪnvɝɾɪd, ɪt hʌŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə mi ən ɔltɝd maɪ wɝdz ɪn ə weɪ aɪɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd.

"I couldn't use it to lie," Seaine said. "I tried. The oaths hold - so long as the weave was there, I couldn't speak words that I knew another would hear as lies, even if they were truth when they left my lips. Regardless, it was an easy weave to develop. Tied off and inverted, it hung in front of me and altered my words in a way I'd indicated.

"θiɝɛɾɪkəli, ɪf mɛsænə hæd ðɪs wiv ɪn fɔɹs, ʃi cʊɾə teɪkən ʌp ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ən swɔɹn wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɪʃt. 'aɪ vaʊ ðəɾ əl laɪ wɛnɛvɝ aɪ fil laɪk ɪt' fəɹ ɪnstəns. ði oʊθ ɹɑd wʊɾə baʊn əɹ wɪð ðət vaʊ, bʌt ðə wivz wʊɾə tʃeɪnʒd ðə saʊnz ɪn ði ɛɹ əz ðeɪ pæst əɹ lɪps. wiɾ əv hɝɾ əɹ seɪɪŋ ðə pɹɑpɝ oʊðz.

"Theoretically, if Mesaana had this weave in force, she could have taken up the Oath Rod and sworn whatever she wished. 'I vow that I will lie whenever I feel like it' for instance. The Oath Rod would have bound her with that vow, but the weaves would have changed the sounds in the air as they passed her lips. We'd have heard her saying the proper oaths.

ɛɡwin ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. ʃiɾ əsum ðət dɪfiɾɪŋ ði oʊθ ɹɑd wəd bi dɪfəkəlt. ən jɛt hɪɹ wɑz ə sɪmpəl wiv keɪpəbəl ə ðə fit. ʃi ʃʊɾə noʊn - nɛvɝ juz ə boʊldɝ wən ə pɛbəl wɪl du, əz əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔfən sɛd.

Egwene gritted her teeth. She'd assumed that defeating the Oath Rod would be difficult. And yet here was a simple weave capable of the feat. She should have known - never use a boulder when a pebble will do, as her mother had often said.

"wɪð ðɪs," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ðeɪ cʊɾə bɪn slɪpɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz . ɪndə ɹæŋks ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ jɪɹz."

"With this," Egwene said, "they could have been slipping Darkfriends . into ranks of the Aes Sedai for years."

"ənlaɪkli," sɹɪn sɛd. "nʌn ə ðə blæk sɪstɝz wi kæptʃɝd nu ʌv ðɪs weɪv. ɪf ðeɪ hæd, ðən ðeɪɾ əv tʃɹaɪd tə juz ɪt wən wi meɪd hɛm ɹɛswɛɹ ði oʊðz. aɪ səspɛk ðəɾ ɪf mɛsænə dʌz noʊ ðɪs tʃɹɪk, ʃi eɪtʃ kɛpt ɪt tə hɝsɛlf. ðə jusfəlnəs ʌv ɪt wəd vænɪʃ wʌns tu mɛni pipəl bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt."

"Unlikely," Saerin said. "None of the Black sisters we captured knew of this wave. If they had, then they'd have tried to use it when we made hem reswear the oaths. I suspect that if Mesaana does know this trick, she h kept it to herself. The usefulness of it would vanish once too many people became aware of it."

"stɪl," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌt də wi du? noʊɪŋ ə ðə wiv, wi kəd pɹɑbli faɪn ə weɪ tə tʃɛk fəɹ ɪt - bʌɾ aɪ daʊt ðət ðə sɪstɝz wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɡoʊ θɹu ðə ɹɛswɛɹɪŋ pɹɑsɛs əɡɛn."

"Still," Egwene said. "What do we do? Knowing of the weave, we could probably find a way to check for it - but I doubt that the sisters would be willing to go through the reswearing process again."

"æn ɪf ɪt wɝ tə kætʃ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən?" jukɪɝi æskt. "ɪt maɪt bi wɝθ ɹʌfəlɪŋ ə fju fɛðɝz tə kætʃ ðə fɑks haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə hɛnhaʊs."

"And if it were to catch one of the Forsaken?" Yukiri asked. "It might be worth ruffling a few feathers to catch the fox hiding in the henhouse."

"ʃi wʊdn bi kɑt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bɪsaɪdz, wi doʊnt noʊ ɪf ʃiz juzɪŋ wʌn ə ðiz mɛθədz. sinz lɑdʒɪk sədʒɛsts ðəɾ ɪt maɪt bi pɑsəbəl - wɪθaʊt tu mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl - tə dɪfit ði oʊθ ɹɑd. ði æktʃəwəl mɛθəd mɛsænə juzd ɪz lɛs ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ði ækt."

"She wouldn't be caught," Egwene said. "Besides, we don't know if she's using one of these methods. Seaine's logic suggests that it might be possible - without too much trouble - to defeat the Oath Rod. The actual method Mesaana used is less important than the possibility of the act."

sin ɡlænst ət jukɪɝi. nʌn ə ðə θɹi hæd kwɛstʃən ɛɡwinz nɑlədʒ ðət wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt ʃi nu ðeɪd bɪn skɛptəkəl. wɛl, ət lis ðeɪ naʊ ʌndɝstʊd ðəɾ ɪt maɪt bi pɑsəbəl tə dɪfit ði oʊθ ɹɑd.

Seaine glanced at Yukiri. None of the three had questioned Egwene's knowledge that one of the Forsaken was in the White Tower, but she knew they'd been skeptical. Well, at least they now understood that it might be possible to defeat the Oath Rod.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə kəntɪnju jəɹ wɝk," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɪfɛktɪv ət kæptʃɝɪŋ sɛvɹəl blæk sɪstɝz ən ənɝθəŋ ðə fɛɹəts. ðɪs ɪz mʌtʃ ðə seɪm θɪŋ." mɪɹli fɑɹ, fɑɹ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs.

"I want you to continue your work," Egwene said. "You and the others were effective at capturing several Black sisters and unearthing the ferrets. This is much the same thing." Merely far, far more dangerous.

"wil tʃɹaɪ, mʌðɝ," jukɪɝi sɛd. "bʌt wʌn sɪstɝ əmʌŋ hʌnʒɹədz? wʌn ə ðə moʊs kɹæfti ən ivəl kɹitʃɝz ɛvɝ tə hæv lɪvd? aɪ daʊt ʃɪl liv mɛni kluz. əɹ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃənz ɪndə ðə mɝɾɝz hæv, soʊ fɑɹ, jildəd vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ɹɪzʌls."

"We'll try, Mother," Yukiri said. "But one sister among hundreds? One of the most crafty and evil creatures ever to have lived? I doubt she will leave many clues. Our investigations into the murders have, so far, yielded very little in the way of results."

"kip əɾ ɪɾ ɛniweɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "sɹɪn, wʌɾ əv jə tə ɹipɔɹt?"

"Keep at it anyway," Egwene said. "Saerin, what have you to report?"

"teɪlz, ɹumɝz ən wɪspɝz, mʌðɝ," sɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. "ju laɪkli noʊ ðə moʊs feɪməs stɔɹiz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ mɛsænə - haʊ ʃi ɹæn ðə skulz ɪn lænz kɑŋkɝd baɪ ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ. soʊ fɑɹ əz aɪ kən tɛl, ðoʊz lɛdʒənz ɑɹ kwaɪt tʃɹu. mɑɹsɪm ə meɪnɛðɝən spiks ə ðəɾ ɪn dɪteɪl ɪn əɹ ænəlz ə ðə faɪnəl naɪts, ən ʃiz ɔfən ə ɹɪlaɪəbəl sɔɹs. ɔlɹəm ɡæðɝd kwaɪɾ ə fʊl ɹipɔɹɾ ə lɪvɪŋ θɹu wʌn ə ðoʊz skulz, ən fɹæɡməns ʌv ɪɾ əv sɝvaɪvd.

"Tales, rumors and whispers, Mother," Saerin said with a grimace. "You likely know the most famous stories regarding Mesaana - how she ran the schools in lands conquered by the Shadow during the War of Power. So far as I can tell, those legends are quite true. Marsim of Manetheren speaks of that in detail in her Annals of the Final Nights, and she's often a reliable source. Alrom gathered quite a full report of living through one of those schools, and fragments of it have survived.

mɛsænə wɪʃt tə bi ə ɹisɝtʃɝ, bʌt wɑz ɹɪdʒɛktɪd. ðə dɪteɪlz ɑɹ nɑt klɪɹ. ʃi ɔlsoʊ ɡʌvɝn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɛn tə ðə ʃædoʊ, lɛd-ɪŋ əm ɪn bæɾəl ət taɪmz, ɪf ɔlɹəmz ɹipɔɹɾ ɪz tə bi bɪlivd. ɪm nɑt kənvɪnst ɪɾ ɪz; aɪ θɪŋk ɪt laɪkli mɛsænəz liɾɝʃɪp wɑz mɔɹ fɪɡjɝəɾɪv."

Mesaana wished to be a researcher, but was rejected. The details are not clear. She also governed the Aes Sedai who went to the Shadow, lead-ing them in battle at times, if Alrom's report is to be believed. I'm not convinced it is; I think it likely Mesaana's leadership was more figurative."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd sloʊli. "bʌt wʌɾ ə hɝ pɝsənælɪɾi? hu ɪz ʃi?"

Egwene nodded slowly. "But what of her personality? Who is she?"

sɹɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ mɔɹ mɑnstɝz ɪn ðə naɪt ðən ɹil 'pɝsənælɪɾiz' tə moʊst, mʌðɝ, ən mʌtʃ əz bɪn lɔst əɹ mɪs-kwoʊɾəd. fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ kən tɛl, əmʌŋ ðə fɔɹseɪkən jə kəd θɪŋk ə hɝ əz ðə ɹilɪst - ðə wʌn hu, ɹæðɝ ðən sɪɾɪŋ haɪ ɑn ə θɹoʊn, stɛps ɪn ən ɡɛts əɹ hænz dɝɾi. ilænʒɹiə bɔɹndæts siɪŋ θɹu ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪnsɪsts ðæt, ənlaɪk mɑɡiɾin ən ɡɹeɪndəl, mɛsænə wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ðə ɹeɪnz dɝɛkli.

Saerin shook her head. "The Forsaken are more monsters in the night than real 'personalities' to most, Mother, and much has been lost or mis-quoted. From what I can tell, among the Forsaken you could think of her as the realist - the one who, rather than sitting high on a throne, steps in and gets her hands dirty. Elandria Borndat's Seeing Through the Breaking insists that, unlike Moghedien and Graendal, Mesaana was willing to take the reins directly.

"ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ noʊn əz ðə moʊst skɪld əɹ paʊɝfəl ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən bʌt ʃi wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli keɪpəbəl. ilænʒɹiə ɪkspleɪnz ðət ʃi dɪd wʌt niɾəd tə bi dʌn. wən ʌðɝz wəd bi skimɪŋ, ʃi wəd bi kɛɹfəli bɪldɪŋ ʌp dɪfɛnsəz ən tʃɹeɪnɪŋ nu ɹəkɹuts." sɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ʃi . . . wɛl, ʃi saʊnz mʌtʃ laɪk ən æmɪɝlɪn, mʌðɝ. ðə ʃædoʊz æmɪɝlɪn."

"She was never known as the most skilled or powerful of the Forsaken but she was extremely capable. Elandria explains that she did what needed to be done. When others would be scheming, she would be carefully building up defenses and training new recruits." Saerin hesitated. "She . . . well, she sounds much like an Amyrlin, Mother. The Shadow's Amyrlin."

"laɪt," jukɪɝi sɛd. "lɪɾəl wʌndɝ ʃi sɛɾ ʌp hɪɹ." ðə ɡɹeɪ sim vɛɹi ənsɛɾəld baɪ ðæt.

"Light," Yukiri said. "Little wonder she set up here." The Gray seemed very unsettled by that.

"ði oʊnli ʌðɝ θɪŋ aɪ kəd faɪn ə ɹɛləvəns, mʌðɝ," sɹɪn sɛd, "wɑz ə kjʊɹiəs ɹɛfɝəns fɹəm ðə blu skɑlɝ lænɪs, hu ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət mɛsænə wɑz sɛkən oʊnli tə dɪmɑndɝɾ ɪn ʃɪɹ æŋɡɝ."

"The only other thing I could find of relevance, Mother," Saerin said, "was a curious reference from the Blue scholar Lannis, who indicated that Mesaana was second only to Demandred in sheer anger."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. "aɪɾ əsum ðəɾ ɔl ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ fʊl ə heɪt."

Egwene frowned. "I'd assume that all of the Forsaken are full of hate."

"nɑt heɪt," sɹɪn sɛd. "æŋɡɝ. lænɪs θɔt mɛsænə wɑz æŋɡɹi - ət hɝsɛlf, ət ðə wɝld, ət ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən - kəz ʃi wɑznt wʌn ə ðoʊz æt/ ðə fɔɹfɹʌnt. ðət kəd meɪk əɹ vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs."

"Not hate," Saerin said. "Anger. Lannis thought Mesaana was angry - at herself, at the world, at the other Forsaken - because she wasn't one of those at/ the forefront. That could make her very dangerous."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd sloʊli. ʃiz ən ɔɹɡənaɪzɝ, ʃi θɔt. ən ədmɪnəstʃɹeɪɾɝ u heɪts biɪŋ ɹɛləɡeɪɾɪd tə ðət pəzɪʃən.

Egwene nodded slowly. She's an organizer, she thought. An administrator who hates being relegated to that position.

wɑz ðət waɪ ʃid steɪɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ æftɝ ðə blæk sɪstɝz hæd bɪn faʊnd? dɪd ʃi dɪzaɪɝ tə bɹɪŋ səm ɡɹeɪɾ əkɑmplɪʃmən tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn? vɛɹɪn hæd sɛd ðət ðə fɔɹseɪkən ʃɛɹd wʌn junəfaɪɪŋ tʃɹeɪt: ðɛɹ sɛlfɪʃnəs.

Was that why she'd stayed in the Tower after the Black sisters had been found? Did she desire to bring some great accomplishment to the Dark One? Verin had said that the Forsaken shared one unifying trait: their selfishness.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə dɪlɪvɝ ə bɹoʊkən waɪt taʊɝ, ɛɡwin θɔt. bʌt ðəɾ əz feɪld. ʃi wɑz pɹɑbli pɑɹɾ ə ði ətɛmp tə kɪdnæp ɹænd əz wɛl. ənʌðɝ fiæskoʊ. ən ðə wɪmən sɛn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə blæk taʊɝ?

She tried to deliver a broken White Tower, Egwene thought. But that has failed. She was probably part of the attempt to kidnap Rand as well. Another fiasco. And the women sent to destroy the Black Tower?

mɛsænə wəd nid sʌmθɪŋ ɡɹæn tə ɔfsɛt soʊ mɛni feɪljɝz. kɪlɪŋ ɛɡwin wəd wɝk.

Mesaana would need something grand to offset so many failures. Killing Egwene would work.

ðət maɪt sɛn ðə waɪt taʊɝ bæk ɪndə dɪvɪʒən.

That might send the White Tower back into division.

ɡɔɪn hæd bɪn mɔɹɾəfaɪd wən ʃid sɛd ʃi maɪt juz hɝsɛlf əz beɪt. dɛɹd ʃi də soʊ? ʃi ɡɹɪp ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, stændɪŋ əbʌv ðə taʊɝ, əbʌv ðə sɪɾi ðət dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn hɝ, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ɑn ə wɝl ðət niɾəd hɝ.

Gawyn had been mortified when she'd said she might use herself as bait. Dared she do so? She gripped the railing, standing above the Tower, above the city that depended on her, looking out on a world that needed her.

sʌmθɪŋ hæd tə bi dʌn; mɛsænə hæd tə bi dʒɹɔn aʊt. ɪf wʌt sɹɪn sɛd wɑz tʃɹu, ðən ðə wʊmən wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə faɪt dɝɛkli - ʃi wʊdn haɪɾ ən poʊk fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz. ɛɡwinz tæsk, ðɛn, wɑz tə tɛmpt əɹ wɪð ən ɑpɝtunəɾi, wʌn ðət dɪdn sim ɑbviəs, wʌn ʃi kʊdn ɹɪzɪst.

Something had to be done; Mesaana had to be drawn out. If what Saerin said was true, then the woman would be willing to fight directly - she wouldn't hide and poke from the shadows. Egwene's task, then, was to tempt her with an opportunity, one that didn't seem obvious, one she couldn't resist.

"kʌm " ɛɡwin sɛd, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹæmp bæk daʊn ɪndə ði "aɪ hæv səm pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz tə meɪk."

"Come " Egwene said, walking toward the ramp back down into the "I have some preparations to make."


tʃæptɝ sɪkstin


CHAPTER 16

ʃænəhɑɹ


Shanna'har

feɪl wɔk ðə kæmp ɪn ðə weɪnɪŋ ivnɪŋ laɪt, meɪkɪŋ əɹ weɪ təwɔɹd ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz tɛnt. pɛɹɪn hæd sɛn ðɛɹ ɡɹup ə skaʊts θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ tə kɛɹhin; ðeɪd ɹɪtɝn ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ.

Faile walked the camp in the waning evening light, making her way toward the quartermaster's tent. Perrin had sent their group of scouts through the gateway to Cairhien; they'd return the next morning.

pɛɹɪn wɑz stɪl bɹuɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks. oʊvɝ ðə læst sɛvɹəl deɪz, ðə tu ɑɹmiz hæɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd sɛvɹəl lɛɾɝz, pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə mənuvɝ fəɹ ə sɛkənd, mɔɹ fɔɹməl pɑɹli waɪl ðə waɪtkloʊks ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ə bæɾəl. feɪl hæd ɡɪvən pɛɹɪn tʃɔɪs wɝdz əbaʊt snikɪŋ ɔf tə mit wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks wɪθaʊt hɝ.

Perrin was still brooding about the Whitecloaks. Over the last several days, the two armies had exchanged several letters, Perrin trying to maneuver for a second, more formal parley while the Whitecloaks insisted on a battle. Faile had given Perrin choice words about sneaking off to meet with the Whitecloaks without her.

pɛɹɪn wɑz stɔlɪŋ əz i lɛɾ ɛlaɪəs ən ði il skaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks tə tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə snik ðɛɹ pipəl aʊt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli tə bi ən ɑpʃən. hid səksiɾəd bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə kæptɪvz ðɛn. naʊ ðəɹ wɝ hʌnʒɹədz.

Perrin was stalling as he let Elyas and the Aiel scout the Whitecloaks to try to find a way to sneak their people out, but it was unlikely to be an option. He'd succeeded back in the Two Rivers, but there had been only a handful of captives then. Now there were hundreds.

pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt dilɪŋ wɛl wɪð ɪz ɡɪlt. wɛl, feɪl wəd tɔk wɪð ɪm ʃɔɹtli. ʃi kəntɪnjud θɹu ðə kæmp, pæsɪŋ ðə minɝ sɛkʃən tə hɝ lɛft, wɪð bænɝz flaɪɪŋ haɪ.

Perrin was not dealing well with his guilt. Well, Faile would talk with him shortly. She continued through the camp, passing the Mayener section to her left, with banners flying high.

əl əv tə dil wɪð ðət wʌn sun əz wɛl, feɪl θɔt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət bɹəleɪnz bænɝ. ðə ɹumɝz əbaʊɾ əɹ ən pɛɹɪn wɝ pɹɑbləmæɾɪk. ʃid səspɛktəd ðət bɹəleɪn maɪt tʃɹaɪ sʌmθɪŋ ɪn feɪlz æbsəns, bʌt teɪkɪŋ ɪm ɪndə hɝ tɛn ət naɪt sim pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli fɔɹwɝd.

I will have to deal with that one soon as well, Faile thought, looking up at Berelain's banner. The rumors about her and Perrin were problematic. She'd suspected that Berelain might try something in Faile's absence, but taking him into her tent at night seemed particularly forward.

feɪlz nɛkst stɛps wəɾ əv tə bi teɪkən wɪð ɪkstʃɹim kɛɹ. hɝ hʌzbənd, hɪz pipəl, ən ɪz ælaɪz wɝ ɔl bæləns pɹɪkɛɹiəsli. feɪl faʊn hɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ ʃi kəɾ æsk əɹ mʌðɝ fəɹ ædvaɪs.

Faile's next steps would have to be taken with extreme care. Her husband, his people, and his allies were all balanced precariously. Faile found herself wishing she could ask her mother for advice.

ðət ʃɑk hɝ, ən ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, stɑpɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔɹn pæθweɪ ʌv tʃɹæmpəl jɛloʊ ɡɹæs ən mʌd. laɪt, feɪl θɔt. lʊk wʌɾ əz hæpən tə mi.

That shocked her, and she hesitated, stopping on the worn pathway of trampled yellow grass and mud. Light, Faile thought. Look what has happened to me.

tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ, feɪl - ðən kɔl zɑɹin - hæd ɹʌn fɹəm əɹ hoʊm ɪn sɑldɑiə tə bɪkʌm ə hʌntɝ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn. ʃid ɹɪbɛld əɡɛnst əɹ duɾiz əz ði ɛldəst, ən ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ʃi ʌndɝɡoʊ.

Two years ago, Faile - then called Zarine - had run from her home in Saldaea to become a Hunter for the Horn. She'd rebelled against her duties as the eldest, and the training her mother had insisted she undergo.

ʃi hædn ɹʌn kəz ʃid heɪɾəd ðə wɝk; ɪndid, ʃid pɹuvən æd-ɛpt əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə hɝ. soʊ waɪ hæd ʃi ɡɔn? ɪn pɑɹt fəɹ ædvɛntʃɝ. bʌɾ ɪn pɑɹt - ʃi ədmɪɾəd tə hɝsɛlf oʊnli naʊ -  kəz ʌv ɔl ði əsʌmpʃənz. ɪn sɑldɑiə, jə ɔlweɪz dɪd wʌt wɑz ɪkspɛktəɾ ə ju. noʊbɑdi wʌndɝɾ ɪf jə wəd də jəɹ duɾi, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪf jə wɝ ə ɹɛləɾɪv ə ðə kwin hɝsɛlf.

She hadn't run because she'd hated the work; indeed, she'd proven ad-ept at everything required of her. So why had she gone? In part for adventure. But in part - she admitted to herself only now -  because of all the assumptions. In Saldaea, you always did what was expected of you. Nobody wondered if you would do your duty, particularly if you were a relative of the Queen herself.

ən soʊ . . . ʃid lɛft. nɑt kəz ʃid heɪɾəd wʌt ʃi wəd bɪkʌm, bʌt kəz ʃi hæd heɪɾəd ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪt hæd sim soʊ ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. naʊ hɪɹ ʃi wɑz, juzɪŋ ɔl ə ðə θɪŋz əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ʃi lɝn.

And so . . . she'd left. Not because she'd hated what she would become, but because she had hated the fact that it had seemed so inevitable. Now here she was, using all of the things her mother had insisted she learn.

ɪt wɑz nɪɹli ɪnʌf tə meɪk feɪl læf. ʃi kəd tɛl ə hoʊst ə θɪŋz əbaʊt ðə kæmp fɹəm ə mɪɹ ɡlæns. ðeɪd nid tə faɪn səm ɡʊd lɛðɝ fəɹ ðə kɑblɝz sun. wɔɾɝ wɑzn ə pɹɑbləm, əz ɪt hæd bɪn ɹeɪnɪŋ laɪt spɹɪŋkəlz ɔfən oʊvɝ ðə læs fju deɪz, bʌt dʒɹaɪ wʊd fəɹ kæmpfaɪɝz wɑz ən ɪʃu. wʌn ɡɹup ə ɹɛfjudʒiz - ə kəlɛkʃən ə fɔɹmɝ wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn u wɑtʃt pɛɹɪnz il wɪð aʊtʃɹaɪt hɑstɪləɾi - wəd niɾ ətɛnʃən. əz ʃi wɔkt, ʃi wɑtʃt tə meɪk sɝɾən ðə kæmp hæd pɹɑpɝ sænəteɪʃən, ən ðət ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz. səm mɛn wəd ʃoʊ ʌtmoʊs kənsɝn fəɹ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ðən fɝɡɛt tə iɾ ɛniθɪŋ pɹɑpɝ - əɹ ət lis hɛlθi. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðɛɹ hæbəɾ ə spɛndɪŋ hæf ðə naɪt ɡɑsəpɪŋ baɪ ðə kæmpfaɪɝz.

It was nearly enough to make Faile laugh. She could tell a host of things about the camp from a mere glance. They'd need to find some good leather for the cobblers soon. Water wasn't a problem, as it had been raining light sprinkles often over the last few days, but dry wood for campfires was an issue. One group of refugees - a collection of former wetlander gai'shain who watched Perrin's Aiel with outright hostility - would need attention. As she walked, she watched to make certain the camp had proper sanitation, and that the soldiers were caring for themselves. Some men would show utmost concern for their horses, then forget to eat anything proper - or at least healthy. Not to mention their habit of spending half the night gossiping by the campfires.

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən kəntɪnjud wɔkɪŋ, ɛntɝɪŋ ðə səplaɪ ɹɪŋ, wɛɹ fud wæɡənz hæd bɪn ənloʊɾəd fəɹ ðə hɔɹɾ ə kʊks ən sɝvɪŋ meɪdz. ðə səplaɪ ɹɪŋ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ə vɪlədʒ ɪtsɛlf, wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ə pipəl kwɪkli wɛɹɪŋ pæθweɪz ɪn ðə mʌɾi ɡɹæs. ʃi pæst ə ɡɹup ə dɝɾi-ɹeɪst juðz dɪɡɪŋ pɪts ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðən ə pætʃ ʌv wɪmən tʃæɾɝɪŋ ən hʌmɪŋ əz ðeɪ pil pəteɪɾoʊz, tʃɪlʒɹən ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə ɹaɪnz ən θɹoʊɪŋ əm ɪndə ðə pɪts. ðəɹ wɝn mɛni ʌv ðoʊz tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌɾ ɛɹɪnz fɔɹs hæd ɡæðɝɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə fæmliz fɹəm ɝaʊn ðə kʌntʃɹi-saɪɾ u -  stɑɹvɪŋ - hæd bɛɡd tə dʒɔɪn.

She shook her head and continued walking, entering the supply ring, where food wagons had been unloaded for the horde of cooks and serving maids. The supply ring was almost a village itself, with hundreds of people quickly wearing pathways in the muddy grass. She passed a group of dirty-raced youths digging pits in the ground, then a patch of women chattering and humming as they peeled potatoes, children gathering the rinds and throwing them into the pits. There weren't many of those children, but errins force had gathered a number of families from around the country-Side who -  starving - had begged to join.

sɝvɪŋ mɛn ɹæn bæskəts ə pil pəteɪɾoʊz tə kʊkɪŋ pɑts, wɪtʃ wɝ sloʊli biɪŋ fɪld wɪð wɔɾɝ baɪ jʌŋ wɪmən meɪkɪŋ tʃɹɪps tə ðə stʃɹim. dʒɝnimæn kʊks pɹipɛɹd koʊlz fəɹ ɹoʊstɪŋ ən oʊldɝ kʊks wɝ mɪksɪŋ spaɪsəz ɪndə sɔsəz ðət kəd bi pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ʌðɝ fudz, wɪtʃ wɑz ɹɪli ði oʊnli weɪ tə ɡɪv fleɪvɝ tə sətʃ mæs kwɑntəɾiz.

Serving men ran baskets of peeled potatoes to cooking pots, which were slowly being filled with water by young women making trips to the stream. Journeyman cooks prepared coals for roasting and older cooks were mixing spices into sauces that could be poured over other foods, which was really the only way to give flavor to such mass quantities.

ɛldɝli wɪmən - ðə fju ɪn ðə kæmp - ʃʌfəl pæst wɪð bɛn bæks ən laɪt wɪkɝ bæskəts bɛɹɪŋ ɝbz klʌtʃt ɑn θɪn ɑɹmz, ðɛɹ ʃɔlz ɹɪpəlɪŋ əz ðeɪ tʃæɾəd wɪð kɹæklɪŋ vɔɪsəz.

Elderly women - the few in the camp - shuffled past with bent backs and light wicker baskets bearing herbs clutched on thin arms, their shawls rippling as they chatted with crackling voices.

soʊlʒɝz hɝiɾ ɪn ən aʊt, kæɹiɪŋ ɡeɪm. bɔɪz bɪtwin tʃaɪldhʊɾ ən mænhʊd ɡæðɝd stɪks fəɹ tɪndɝ; ʃi pæst ə smɔl ɡæɡəl ə ðiz u hæd ɡɹoʊn dɪstʃɹæktəd kæp-tʊɹɪŋ spaɪɾɝz.

Soldiers hurried in and out, carrying game. Boys between childhood and manhood gathered sticks for tinder; she passed a small gaggle of these who had grown distracted cap-turing spiders.

ɪt wɑz ə tɛmpəst ə kənfjuʒən ən ɔɹɾɝ koʊɪɡzɪstɪŋ, laɪk tu saɪdz ʌv ə kɔɪn. stʃɹeɪnʒ haʊ wɛl feɪl fɪɾ ɪn hɪɹ. lʊkɪŋ bæk ət hɝsɛlf oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ, ʃi wɑz əmeɪz tə ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi sɔ ə spɔɪld, sɛlf-sɛntɝd tʃaɪld. livɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz tə bɪkʌm ə hʌntɝ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn? ʃiɾ əbændən duɾiz, hoʊm ən fæmli. wʌt hæd ʃi bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ?

It was a tempest of confusion and order coexisting, like two sides of a coin. Strange how well Faile fit in here. Looking back at herself only a few years before, she was amazed to realize that she saw a spoiled, self-centered child. Leaving the Borderlands to become a Hunter for the Horn? She'd abandoned duties, home and family. What had she been thinking?

ʃi pæst səm wɪmən mɪlɪŋ ɡɹeɪn, ðən wɔkt ɝaʊn ə fɹɛʃ bætʃ ʌv waɪl skæljənz laɪɪŋ ɑn ə blæŋkət bɪsaɪd ðɛm, weɪɾɪŋ tə bi meɪɾ ɪndə sup. ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ʃid lɛft ən mɛt pɛɹɪn, bʌt ðət dɪdn ɪkskjuz əɹ ækʃənz. wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɔɹsɪŋ pɛɹɪn tə tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, əloʊn. ʃi dɪdn ivən ɹikɔl wʌt hid dʌn tə sɛɾ əɹ ɔf, ðoʊ ʃid nɛvɝ ədmɪt ðət tə hɪm.

She passed some women milling grain, then walked around a fresh batch of wild scallions lying on a blanket beside them, waiting to be made into soup. She was glad she'd left and met Perrin, but that didn't excuse her actions. With a grimace, she remembered forcing Perrin to travel the Ways in the darkness, alone. She didn't even recall what he'd done to set her off, though she'd never admit that to him.

hɝ mʌðɝ hæd wʌns kɔld əɹ spɔɪld, ən ʃid bɪn ɹaɪt. hɝ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlsoʊ ɪnsɪstəd ðət feɪl lɝn tə ɹʌn ði ɪsteɪts, ən ɔl ðə waɪl feɪl hæd dʒɹimd ə mɛɹiɪŋ ə hʌntɝ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn ən spɛndɪŋ əɹ laɪf fɑɹ əweɪ fɹəm ɑɹmiz ən ðə bɔɹɪŋ duɾiz ə lɔɹdz.

Her mother had once called her spoiled, and she'd been right. Her mother had also insisted that Faile learn to run the estates, and all the while Faile had dreamed of marrying a Hunter for the Horn and spending her life far away from armies and the boring duties of lords.

laɪt blɛs ju, mʌðɝ, feɪl θɔt. wʌt wəd ʃi, əɹ pɛɹɪn, hæv dʌn wɪθaʊt ðət tʃɹeɪnɪŋ? wɪθaʊɾ əɹ mʌðɝz titʃɪŋz, feɪl wʊɾə bɪn jusləs. ædmɪnɪstʃɹeɪʃən ə ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp wʊɾə ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɝɑvinz ʃoʊldɝz. keɪpəbəl ðoʊ ðə wʊmən wɑz əz pɛɹɪnz kæmp stuɝd, ʃi kʊdn əv mænədʒ ðɪs ɔl ɑn əɹ oʊn. nɔɹ ʃəd ʃi hæv bɪn ɪkspɛktəd tə.

Light bless you, Mother, Faile thought. What would she, or Perrin, have done without that training? Without her mother's teachings, Faile would have been useless. Administration of the entire camp would have rested on Aravine's shoulders. Capable though the woman was as Perrin's camp steward, she couldn't have managed this all on her own. Nor should she have been expected to.

feɪl ɹitʃt ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz steɪʃən, ə smɔl pəvɪljən ət ðə vɛɹi hɑɹɾ ə ðə kʊkɪŋ pɪts.

Faile reached the quartermaster's station, a small pavilion at the very heart of the cooking pits.

ðə bɹiz bɹɔɾ ən əmælɡəmeɪʃən ə sɛns: fæt sɪɹd baɪ fleɪmz, pəteɪɾoʊz bɔɪlɪŋ, pɛpɝd sɔsəz spaɪst wɪð ɡɑɹlɪk, ðə wɛt, stɪki sɛn ə pəteɪtoʊ piilɪŋz biɪŋ kæɹid tə ðə smɔl hɝɾ əɹ hɑɡz ðeɪd mænədʒ tə bɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə meɪɾən.

The breeze brought an amalgamation of scents: fat seared by flames, potatoes boiling, peppered sauces spiced with garlic, the wet, sticky scent of potato peelings being carried to the small herd or hogs they'd managed to bring out of Maiden.

ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ, beɪvɪn ɹɑkʃɔ, wɑz ə peɪl-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn wɪð blɑn spɛkəl θɹu hɪz ɡɹeɪɪŋ bɹaʊn hɛɹ, laɪk ðə fɝ ɑn ə mɪkst-bɹid dɔɡ. hi wɑz spɪnli θɹu ði ɑɹmz, lɛɡz ən tʃɛst, jɛt hæɾ ən ɔlmoʊs pɝfəkli ɹaʊn pɔntʃ. hi hæɾ əpɛɹənli wɝkt ət dʒeɪ kɔɹɾɝmæstɝɪŋ əz fɑɹ bæk əz ði il wɔɹ, ən wɑz ən ɛkspɝt - ə mæstɝ əz pɹæktəst ɪn oʊvɝsiɪŋ səplaɪ ɑpɝeɪʃənz əz ə mæstɝ kɑɹpəntɝ wɑz ət wʊdwɝkɪŋ.

The quartermaster, Bavin Rockshaw, was a pale-faced Cairhienin with blond speckled through his graying brown hair, like the fur on a mixed-breed dog. He was spindly through the arms, legs and chest, yet had an almost perfectly round paunch. He had apparently worked at j quartermastering as far back as the Aiel War, and was an expert - a master as practiced in overseeing supply operations as a master carpenter was at woodworking.

ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs, mɛn ðəɾ i wɑz ən ɛkspɝɾ ət teɪkɪŋ bɹaɪbz. wən sɔ feɪl, hi smaɪld ən baʊd stɪfli ɪnʌf tə bi fɔɹməl, bʌt wɪθaʊt mɛnteɪʃən. "ɪm ə sɪmpəl soʊlʒɝ, duɪŋ ɪz duɾi," ðət baʊ sɛd.

That, of course, meant that he was an expert at taking bribes. When saw Faile, he smiled and bowed stiffly enough to be formal, but without mentation. "I'm a simple soldier, doing his duty," that bow said.

"leɪɾi feɪl!" hi ɪkskleɪmd, weɪvɪŋ oʊvɝ səm ə hɪz sɝvɪŋ mɛn. "hɪɹ tə ɪnspɛk ðə lɛdʒɝz, aɪ əsum?"

"Lady Faile!" he exclaimed, waving over some of his serving men. "Here to inspect the ledgers, I assume?"

"jɛs, beɪvɪn," ʃi sɛd, ðoʊ ʃi nu ðəɹ wəd bi nʌθɪŋ səspɪʃəs ɪn ðɛm. hi wɑz fɑɹ tu kɛɹfəl. stɪl, ʃi meɪɾ ə kɝsɝi moʊʃən ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹɛkɝdz. wʌn ə ðə mɛn bɹɔɾ əɹ ə stul, ənʌðɝ ə teɪbəl əpɑn wɪtʃ tə pleɪs ðə lɛdʒɝz, ən jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ə kʌp ə ti. ʃi wɑz ɪmpɹɛst ət haʊ nitli ðə kɑl-ʌmz æɾəd ʌp. hɝ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ ɔfən, ə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ wəd meɪk mɛni mɛsi noʊteɪʃənz, ɹɛfɝənsɪŋ ʌðɝ peɪdʒəz əɹ ʌðɝ lɛdʒɝz, sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ dɪfɹən taɪps ə səplaɪz ɪndə dɪfɹən bʊks, ɔl tə meɪk ɪt mɔɹ dɪfəkəl tə tʃɹæk wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. ə liɾɝ u wɑz bɪfʌɾəld baɪ ðə noʊteɪʃənz wəɾ əsum ðət ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ mʌs bi duɪŋ ɪz dʒɑb.

"Yes, Bavin," she said, though she knew there would be nothing suspicious in them. He was far too careful. Still, she made a cursory motion of going through the records. One of the men brought her a stool, another a table upon which to place the ledgers, and yet another a cup of tea. She was impressed at how neatly the col-umns added up. Her mother had explained that often, a quartermaster would make many messy notations, referencing other pages or other ledgers, separating different types of supplies into different books, all to make it more difficult to track what was going on. A leader who was befuddled by the notations would assume that the quartermaster must be doing his job.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌn ə ðət hɪɹ. wʌtɛvɝ tʃɹɪks ə nʌmbɝɪŋ beɪvɪn wɑz juzɪŋ tə əbskjʊɹ ɪz θivɝi, ðeɪ wɝ nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə mædʒɪkəl. ən i wɑz stilɪŋ, əɹ ət lis biɪŋ kɹieɪɾɪv ɪn haʊ hi doʊld aʊɾ ɪz fudstʌfs. ðət wɑz ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. moʊs kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz dɪdn ɹɪli kənsɪɾɝ ɪt θivɝi;

There was none of that here. Whatever tricks of numbering Bavin was using to obscure his thievery, they were nothing short of magical. And he was stealing, or at least being creative in how he doled out his foodstuffs. That was inevitable. Most quartermasters didn't really consider it thievery;

hi wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə hɪz səplaɪz, ən ðət wɑz ðæt.

he was in charge of his supplies, and that was that.

"haʊ ɑɾ ɪɾ ɪz," feɪl sɛɾ əz ʃi lif θɹu ðə lɛdʒɝ. "ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ twɪsts ə feɪt."

"How odd it is," Faile said as she leafed through the ledger. "The strange twists of fate."

"maɪ leɪɾi?" beɪvɪn æskt.

"My Lady?" Bavin asked.

"m? oʊ, ɪts nʌθɪŋ. oʊnli ðət tɔɹvən ɹɪkʃənz kæmp əz ɹəsiv ðɛɹ milz itʃ ivnɪŋ ə ɡʊɾ aʊɝ əhɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝ kæmps. aɪm sɝɾən ðæts dʒʌs baɪ tʃæns."

"Hmm? Oh, it is nothing. Only that Torven Rikshan's camp has received their meals each evening a good hour ahead of the other camps. I'm certain that's just by chance."

beɪvɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "əndaʊɾɪdli, maɪ leɪɾi."

Bavin hesitated. "Undoubtedly, my Lady."

ʃi kəntɪnjud tə lif θɹu ðə lɛdʒɝz. tɔɹvən ɹɪkʃən wɑz ə kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹd, ən hæd bɪn pleɪst ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv wʌn ə ðə twɛnti kæmps wɪðɪn ðə lɑɹdʒɝ mæs ə ɹɛfjudʒiz. hi hæɾ ən juʒəwəli lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə noʊbəlz ɪn ɪz pɝtɪkjəlɝ kæmp. ɝɑvin hæd bɹɔt ðɪs tə feɪlz ətɛnʃən; ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt tɔɹvən hæd ɡɪvən tə ɹəsiv səplaɪz fəɹ milz mɔɹ kwɪkli, bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn du. ði ʌðɝ kæmps maɪt fil ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz feɪvɝɪŋ wʌn oʊvɝ ənʌðɝ.

She continued to leaf through the ledgers. Torven Rikshan was a Cairhienin lord, and had been placed in charge of one of the twenty camps within the larger mass of refugees. He had an usually large number of nobles in his particular camp. Aravine had brought this to Faile's attention; she wasn't certain what Torven had given to receive supplies for meals more quickly, but it wouldn't do. The other camps might feel that Perrin was favoring one over another.

jɛs," feɪl sɛd, læfɪŋ laɪtli. "mɪɹli koʊɪnsɪɾəns. ðiz θɪŋz hæpən ɪn ə kæmp soʊ lɑɹdʒ.

Yes," Faile said, laughing lightly. "Merely coincidence. These things happen in a camp so large.

waɪ, dʒʌs ði ʌðɝ deɪ vɑɹkəl ʃiəs wɑz kəmpleɪnɪŋ tə mi ðəɾ i hæd pʊɾ ɪn ə ɹɛkwəzɪʃən fəɹ kænvəs tə ɹɪpɛɹ tɔɹn tɛns, bʌt hæzən hæɾ ɪz kænvəs fəɹ nɪɹli ə wik naʊ. jɛɾ aɪ noʊ fəɹ ə fæk ðət sɔfi mɔɹəɾən ɹɪpt əɹ tɛn dʊɹɪŋ ðə stʃɹim kɹɔsɪŋ bʌt hæɾ ɪt ɹɪpɛɹd baɪ ðəɾ ivnɪŋ."

Why, just the other day Varkel Tius was complaining to me that he had put in a requisition for canvas to repair torn tents, but hasn't had his canvas for nearly a week now. Yet I know for a fact that Soffi Moraton ripped her tent during the stream crossing but had it repaired by that evening."

beɪvɪn wɑz saɪlənt.

Bavin was silent.

feɪl meɪd noʊ ækjəzeɪʃənz. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd kɑʃən ðəɾ ə ɡʊd kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ wɑz tu væljəbəl tə tɔs ɪndə pɹɪzən, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən ðə nɛks mæn wɑz laɪkli tə bi hæf əz keɪpəbəl ən ikwəli kɝʌpt. feɪlz duɾi wɑz nɑt tə ɪkspoʊz əɹ ɪmbɛɹəs beɪvɪn. ɪt wɑz tə meɪk ɪm wɝiɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i kɛp hɪmsɛlf ɪn tʃɛk. "pɝhæps jə kən də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðiz ɪɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾiz, beɪvɪn," ʃi sɛd, kloʊzɪŋ ðə lɛdʒɝ. "aɪ loʊð tə bɝɾən jə wɪð sɪli mæɾɝz, bʌt ðə pɹɑbləmz mʌs nɑt ɹitʃ maɪ hʌzbənz ɪɹz. jə noʊ haʊ hiz wən ɛnɹeɪdʒd."

Faile made no accusations. Her mother had cautioned that a good quartermaster was too valuable to toss into prison, particularly when the next man was likely to be half as capable and equally corrupt. Faile's duty was not to expose or embarrass Bavin. It was to make him worried enough that he kept himself in check. "Perhaps you can do something about these irregularities, Bavin," she said, closing the ledger. "I loathe to burden you with silly matters, but the problems must not reach my husband's ears. You know how he is when enraged."

æktʃəli , pɛɹɪn wɑz əbaʊɾ əz laɪkli tə hɝɾ ə mæn laɪk beɪvɪn əz feɪl wɑz tə flæp əɹ ɑɹmz ən flaɪ əweɪ. bʌt ðə kæmp dɪdn si ɪt ðət weɪ. ðeɪ hɝd ɹɪpɔɹts ə pɛɹɪnz fjʊɹi ɪn bæɾəl, əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ əkeɪʒənəl ɑɹɡjəməns wɪð ɪm - pɹəvoʊk baɪ feɪl soʊ ðət ðeɪ kəɾ əv ə pɹɑpɝ dɪskʌʃən- ən əsumd i hæɾ ə tɛɹəbəl tɛmpɝ. ðət wɑz ɡʊd, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ θɔɾ ə hɪm əz ɑnɝəbəl ən kaɪnd. pɹətɛktɪv ə hɪz pipəl, jɛt fɪld wɪð ɹeɪdʒ ət ðoʊz u kɹɔs hɪm.

Actually, Perrin was about as likely to hurt a man like Bavin as Faile was to flap her arms and fly away. But the camp didn't see it that way. They heard reports of Perrin's fury in battle, along with her occasional arguments with him - provoked by Faile so that they could have a proper discussion- and assumed he had a terrible temper. That was good, so long as they also thought of him as honorable and kind. Protective of his people, yet filled with rage at those who crossed him.

ʃi ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə stul, hændɪŋ ðə lɛdʒɝz tə wʌn ə ðə mɛn, kɝli-hɛɹɾ ən wɪð ɪŋk steɪnz ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən dʒɝkɪn. ʃi smaɪld ət beɪvɪn, ðən meɪd hɛt weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə səplaɪ ɹɪŋ. ʃi noʊɾəd wɪð dɪsplɛʒɝ ðət ðə bʌntʃ ɑpwaɪl skæljənz bɪsaɪd ðə pæθweɪ hæd spɔɪld ɪn ðə moʊməns sɪns ʃid sin əm læst, ðɛɹ stɔks mɛltəɾ ən ɹʌni, əz ɪf ðeɪd bɪn ɹɑɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn fəɹ wiks. ðiz spɔɪlɪŋz hæd bɪɡʌn oʊnli ɹisənli ɪnsaɪɾ ə kæmp, bʌt baɪ ɹɪpɔɹts, ɪt hæpən fɑɹ mɔɹ fɹikwənli aʊɾ ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd.

She rose from the stool, handing the ledgers to one of the men, curly-haired and with ink stains on his fingers and jerkin. She smiled at Bavin, then made het way out of the supply ring. She noted with displeasure that the bunch oPwild scallions beside the pathway had spoiled in the moments since she'd seen them last, their stalks melted and runny, as if they'd been rotting in the sun for weeks. These spoilings had begun only recently inside of camp, but by reports, it happened far more frequently out in the countryside.

ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl ði aʊɝ wɪð ðə skaɪ soʊ fʊl ə klaʊdz, bʌɾ ɪt sim fɹəm ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ hɝaɪzən ðəɾ əɹ taɪm tə mit wɪð pɛɹɪn hæd kʌm. feɪl smaɪld. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd wɔɹn əɹ wʌt wəd hæpən tə hɝ, hæd toʊld əɹ wʌt wɑz ɪkspɛktəɾ ə hɝ, ən feɪl hæd wɝid ðət ʃi wəd fil tʃɹæp baɪ laɪf.

It was hard to tell the hour with the sky so full of clouds, but it seemed from the darkening horizon that her time to meet with Perrin had come. Faile smiled. Her mother had warned her what would happen to her, had told her what was expected of her, and Faile had worried that she would feel trapped by life.

bʌt wʌt dʒɹə hædn mɛnʃənd wɑz haʊ fʊlfɪlɪŋ ɪt wəd bi. pɛɹɪn meɪd ðə dɪfɝəns. ɪt wɑz noʊ tʃɹæp əɾ ɔl tə bi kɑt wɪð hɪm.

But what Deira hadn't mentioned was how fulfilling it would be. Perrin made the difference. It was no trap at all to be caught with him.

pɛɹɪn stʊd wɪð wʌn fʊɾ ʌp ɑn ðə stʌmp ʌv ə fɛl tʃɹi, feɪsɪŋ nɔɹθ. ðə hɪltɑp lɛɾ ɪm lʊk aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə pleɪnz təwɔɹd ðə klɪfs ʌv ɡæɹənz wɔl ɹaɪzɪŋ laɪk ðə nʌkəlz ʌv ə slʌmbɝɪŋ dʒaɪənt.

Perrin stood with one foot up on the stump of a felled tree, facing north. The hilltop let him look out over the plains toward the cliffs of Garens Wall rising like the knuckles of a slumbering giant.

hi oʊpən ɪz maɪnd, kwɛstɪŋ aʊt fəɹ wʊlvz. ðəɹ wɝ səm ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ɔlmoʊs tu feɪn tə fil. wʊlvz steɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm lɑɹdʒ ɡæðɝɪŋz ə mɛn.

He opened his mind, questing out for wolves. There were some in the distance, almost too faint to feel. Wolves stayed away from large gatherings of men.

ðə kæmp spɹɛɾ aʊt bɪhaɪn hɪm, wɑtʃfaɪɝz flʌɾɝɪŋ əɾ ɪts baʊndɝiz.

The camp spread out behind him, watchfires fluttering at its boundaries.

ðɪs hɪlsaɪd wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ tə bi sɪkluɾɪd, bʌt nɑt soʊ dɪstən əz tə bi sɑlətɛɹi hi wɑzn sɝɾən waɪ feɪl hæɾ æskt ɪm tə miɾ əɹ hɪɹ ət dʌsk, ʃid smɛld ɪksaɪɾəd, soʊ hi hædn pɹaɪd. wɪmən laɪk ðɛɹ sikɹəts.

This hillside was far enough away to be secluded, but not so distant as to be solitary He wasn't certain why Faile had asked him to meet her here at dusk, she'd smelled excited, so he hadn't pried. Women liked their secrets.

hi hɝd feɪl kʌmɪŋ ʌp ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɪl, stɛpɪŋ sɔfli ɑn ðə wɛt ɡɹæs. ʃi wɑz ɡʊɾ ət biɪŋ kwaɪət - nɑt nɪɹli əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛlaɪəs əɹ wʌn ə ði il, bʌt bɛɾɝ ðən wʌn maɪt θɪŋk ə hɝ. bʌɾ i kəd smɛl əɹ sɛnt, soʊp wɪð lævəndɝ. ʃi juz ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ soʊp oʊnli ɑn deɪz ʃi dim spɛʃəl.

He heard Faile coming up the side of the hill, stepping softly on the wet grass. She was good at being quiet - not nearly as good as Elyas or one of the Aiel, but better than one might think of her. But he could smell her cent, soap with lavender. She used that particular soap only on days she deemed special.

ʃi stɛpt ətɑp ðə hɪlsaɪd, bjuɾəfəl, ɪmpɹɛsɪv. ʃi wɔɹ ə vaɪəlɪt vɛst oʊvɝ ə lɔŋ sɪlk blaʊs ʌv ə laɪɾɝ ʃeɪd. wɛɹ hæd ʃi ɡɑɾən ðə kloʊðɪŋ? hi hædn sin əɹ ɪn ðɪs faɪn aʊtfɪt bɪfɔɹ.

She stepped atop the hillside, beautiful, impressive. She wore a violet vest over a long silk blouse of a lighter shade. Where had she gotten the clothing? He hadn't seen her in this fine outfit before.

"maɪ hʌzbənd," ʃi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm. hi kəd feɪnli hɪɹ əθ-' ɝz nɪɹ ðə fʊɾ ə ðə hɪl  - pɹɑbli tʃɑ feɪl. ʃid lɛft əm bɪhaɪnd. "ju lʊk kənsɝnd."

"My husband," she said, stepping up to him. He could faintly hear oth-' ers near the foot of the hill  - probably Cha Faile. She'd left them behind. "You look concerned."

"ɪts maɪ fɔl ðət ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ kæptʃɝd, feɪl," hi sɛd. "maɪ feɪljɝz kəntɪnju tə maʊnt. ɪts ə wʌndɝ ɛniwʌn fɑloʊz mi."

"It's my fault that Gill and the others were captured, Faile," he said. "My failures continue to mount. It's a wonder anyone follows me."

"pɛɹɪn," ʃi sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. "wiv spoʊkən ə ðɪs. jə mʌsnt seɪ sətʃ θɪŋz."

"Perrin," she said, laying a hand on his arm. "We've spoken of this. You mustn't say such things."

"waɪ?"

"Why?"

"bɪkɔz aɪv nɛvɝ noʊn jə tə bi ə laɪɝ," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə sɔfli tʃaɪɾɪŋ toʊn.

"Because I've never known you to be a liar," she said with a softly chiding tone.

hi lʊkt ət hɝ. ɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹk, ðoʊ hi kəd stɪl meɪk aʊt dɪteɪlz. ʃiɾ əv ə hɑɹɾɝ taɪm siɪŋ ðɛm.

He looked at her. It was growing dark, though he could still make out details. She'd have a harder time seeing them.

"waɪ dʒju kəntɪnju tə faɪt ðɪs?" ʃi æskt. "ju ɑɹ ə ɡʊd liɾɝ, pɛɹɪn."

"Why do you continue to fight this?" she asked. "You are a good leader, Perrin."

"aɪ wʊdn əv ɡɪvən maɪsɛlf ʌp fəɹ ðɛm," hi sɛd.

"I wouldn't have given myself up for them," he said.

ʃi fɹaʊnd. "wʌt dʌz ðəɾ əv tə - "

She frowned. "What does that have to - "

"bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, lʊkɪŋ nɔɹθ əɡɛn, "aɪ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə də ɪt. wən ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd mæts fæmli ən ðə luhənz, aɪɾ əv ɡɪvən maɪsɛlf ʌp. ðɪs taɪm, aɪ wʊdn hæv. ivən wən aɪ spoʊk tə ðɛɹ liɾɝ, æskɪŋ ɪz pɹaɪs, aɪ nu aɪ wʊdnt ɡɪv maɪsɛlf ʌp."

"Back in the Two Rivers," Perrin said, turning away from her, looking north again, "I was ready to do it. When the Whitecloaks had Mat's family and the Luhhans, I'd have given myself up. This time, I wouldn't have. Even when I spoke to their leader, asking his price, I knew I wouldn't give myself up."

jəɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ ə bɛɾɝ liɾɝ."

You're becoming a better leader."

haʊ kən jə seɪ ðæt? aɪm ɡɹoʊɪŋ kæləs, feɪl. ɪf jə nu ðə θɪŋz aɪ dɪd tə ɡɛt jə bæk, ðə θɪŋz aɪ wʊɾə dʌn . . ." hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə hæmɝ əɾ ɪz saɪd. ðə tuθ əɹ ðə klɔ, jʌŋ bʊl, ɪt mæɾɝz nɑt. hid θɹoʊn əweɪ ði æks, bʌt kəɾ i bleɪm ɪt fəɹ ɪz bɹutæləɾi? ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə tul. hi kəd juz ðə hæmɝ tə də ðə seɪm tɛɹəbəl θɪŋz.

How can you say that? I'm growing callous, Faile. If you knew the things I did to get you back, the things I would have done . . ." He fingered the hammer at his side. The tooth or the claw, Young Bull, it matters not. He'd thrown away the axe, but could he blame it for his brutality? It was only a tool. He could use the hammer to do the same terrible things.

ɪts nɑt kæləs," feɪl sɛd, "ɔɹ sɛlfɪʃ. jəɹ ə lɔɹd naʊ, ən jə kæn lɛɾ ɪt bi noʊn ðət kæptʃɝɪŋ jəɹ sʌbʒɪkts wɪl ʌndɝmaɪn jəɹ ɹul. dʒju θɪŋk kwin mɔɹɡeɪs wəɾ æbdəkeɪt tə taɪɹəns u kɪdnæpt əɹ səbdʒɛks? noʊ liɾɝ kəd ɹul ðət weɪ. jəɹ ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə stɑp ivəl mɛn dʌz nɑt meɪk jə ivəl jɝsɛlf."

Its not callous," Faile said, "or selfish. You're a lord now, and you can't let it be known that capturing your subjects will undermine your rule. Do you think Queen Morgase would abdicate to tyrants who kidnapped her subjects? No leader could rule that way. Your inability to stop evil men does not make you evil yourself."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðɪs mæntəl, feɪl. aɪ nɛvɝ hæv."

"I don't want this mantle, Faile. I never have."

"aɪ noʊ."

"I know."

"səmtaɪmz aɪ wɪʃ aɪd nɛvɝ lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. aɪ wɪʃ aɪd lɛt ɹæn ɹʌn ɔf tə hɪz dɛstəni, livɪŋ ɹɛɡjəlɝ foʊk bɪhaɪn tə lɪv ðɛɹ laɪvz."

"Sometimes I wish I'd never left the Two Rivers. I wish I'd let Ran run off to his destiny, leaving regular folk behind to live their lives."

hi kɑɾ ə sɛn ʌv ənɔɪəns fɹəm hɝ.

He caught a scent of annoyance from her.

"bʌɾ ɪf aɪd steɪd," hi æɾəd heɪstəli, "aɪd nɛvɝ əv mɛt ju. soʊ aɪm ɡlæɾ aɪ lɛft. aɪm dʒʌst seɪɪŋ əl bi ɡlæd wən ðɪs ɪz ɔl θɹu ən fɪnɪʃt ən aɪ kən ɡoʊ bæk tə sʌmpleɪs sɪmpəl."

"But if I'd stayed," he added hastily, "I'd never have met you. So I'm glad I left. I'm just saying I'll be glad when this is all through and finished and I can go back to someplace simple."

"ju θɪŋk ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪl ɛvɝ ɡoʊ bæk tə biɪŋ ðə weɪ jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt?"

"You think the Two Rivers will ever go back to being the way you remember it?"

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt - wən ðeɪd ɡɔn, ɪt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn ʃoʊɪŋ saɪnz ə tʃeɪnʒ.

He hesitated. She was right - when they'd gone, it had already been showing signs of change.

ɹɛfjudʒiz fɹəm əkɹɔs ðə maʊntənz muvɪŋ ɪn, ðə vɪlədʒəz swɛlɪŋ. naʊ, wɪð soʊ mɛni mɛn dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪm ɪn wɔɹ, ɡɛɾɪŋ aɪdiəz ɪndə ðɛɹ hɛdz əbaʊt hævɪŋ ə lɔɹd . . .

Refugees from across the mountains moving in, the villages swelling. Now, with so many men joining him in war, getting ideas into their heads about having a lord . . .

"aɪ kəd faɪn sʌmpleɪs ɛls," hi sɛd, filɪŋ stʌbɝn. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ vɪlədʒəz. ðeɪ woʊn ɔl tʃeɪnʒ."

"I could find someplace else," he said, feeling stubborn. "There are other villages. They won't all change."

"æn jud dʒɹæɡ mi ɔf tə wʌn ə ðiz vɪlədʒəz, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?" ʃi sɛd.

"And you'd drag me off to one of these villages, Perrin Aybara?" she said.

"aɪ . . ." wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf feɪl, hɪz bjuɾəfəl feɪl, wɝ kənfaɪn tə ə slipi vɪlədʒ? hi ɔlweɪz ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ i wɑz oʊnli ə blæksmɪθ. bʌt wɑz feɪl ə blæksmɪθs waɪf? "aɪ wəd nɛvɝ fɔɹs jə tə də ɛniθɪŋ, feɪl," hi sɛd, kʌpɪŋ əɹ feɪs ɪn ɪz hænd. hi ɔlweɪz fɛlt ɑkwɝd wən tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ sæɾən tʃiks wɪð ɪz θɪk, kælʌz fɪŋɡɝz.

"I . . ." What would happen if Faile, his beautiful Faile, were confined to a sleepy village? He always insisted that he was only a blacksmith. But was Faile a blacksmith's wife? "I would never force you to do anything, Faile," he said, cupping her face in his hand. He always felt awkward when touching her satin cheeks with his thick, callused fingers.

"aɪd ɡoʊ, ɪf jə ɹɪli wɑntəd mi tə," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. ðət wɑz ɑd. hid nɔɹməli ɪkspɛkt ə snæp fɹəm əɹ əɾ ɪz ɑkwɝd tʌŋ. "bʌɾ ɪz ɪt wʌt jə wɑnt? ɪz ɪt ɹɪli?"

"I'd go, if you really wanted me to," she replied. That was odd. He'd normally expect a snap from her at his awkward tongue. "But is it what you want? Is it really?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt," hi sɛd fɹæŋkli. noʊ, hi dɪdnt wɑnə dʒɹæɡ feɪl ɔf tə ə vɪlədʒ.

"I don't know what I want," he said frankly. No, he didn't want to drag Faile off to a village.

"meɪbi . . . laɪf əz ə blæksmɪθ ɪn ə sɪɾi, sʌmwɛɹ?

"Maybe . . . life as a blacksmith in a city, somewhere?

"ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt," ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd. "ʌv kɔɹs, ðət wəd liv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪθaʊɾ ə lɔɹd. ðeɪɾ əv tə faɪn sʌmwʌn ɛls."

"If you wish it," she repeated. "Of course, that would leave the Two Rivers without a lord. They'd have to find someone else."

"noʊ. ðeɪ doʊnt niɾ ə lɔɹd. ðæts waɪ aɪ hæv tə stɑp əm tʃɹiɾɪŋ mi laɪk wʌn."

"No. They don't need a lord. That's why I have to stop them treating me like one."

"æn jə θɪŋk ðeɪd ɡɪv ʌp ɑn ði aɪdiə ðət kwɪkli?" feɪl æskt, smɛlɪŋ əmjuzd. "æftɝ ðeɪv sin haʊ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls dʌz ɪt? æftɝ ðə weɪ ðeɪ fɔn oʊvɝ ðət ful luk? æftɝ wɛlkəmɪŋ ɪn ɔl ə ðoʊz pipəl fɹəm ɑlməθ pleɪn, hu ɑɹ juz tə lɔɹdz?"

"And you think they'd give up on the idea that quickly?" Faile asked, smelling amused. "After they've seen how everyone else does it? After the way they fawned over that fool Luc? After welcoming in all of those people from Almoth Plain, who are used to lords?"

wʌt wəd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk də ɪf i stɛp daʊn əz ðɛɹ lɔɹd.

What would the Two Rivers folk do if he stepped down as their lord.

ɪn ə sɪŋkɪŋ moʊmən ə ɹiləzeɪʃən, hi nu ðət feɪl wɑz ɹaɪt. ʃʊɹli ðeɪd pɪk sʌmwʌn hud də ə bɛɾɝ dʒɑb ʌv ɪt ðən mi, hi θɔt. meɪbi mæstɝ ælvɪɹ.

In a sinking moment of realization, he knew that Faile was right. Surely they'd pick someone who'd do a better job of it than me, he thought. Maybe Master al'Vere.

bʌt kəd pɛɹɪn tʃɹʌs ðæt? mɛn laɪk mæstɝ ælvɪɹ əɹ tɑɹn maɪt daʊn ðə pəzɪʃən. maɪt ðeɪ ɛn ʌp pɪkɪŋ sʌmwʌn laɪk oʊl sɛn bui? wəd ðeɪv ə tʃɔɪs? ɪf pɛɹɪn stɛpt əsaɪd, maɪt səm pɝsən u fɪɡjɝd hɪmsɛlf haɪbɹn siz paʊɝ?

But could Perrin trust that? Men like Master al'Vere or Tarn might down the position. Might they end up picking someone like old Cenn Buie? Would they have a choice? If Perrin stepped aside, might some person who figured himself highborn seize power?

pɑn bi ə ful, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, hi θɔt. ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn wəd bi bɛɾɝ ðən ju.

pon't be a fool, Perrin Aybara, he thought. Almost anyone would be better than you.

stɪl, ðə θɔɾ ə sʌmwʌn ɛls teɪkɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl - sʌmwʌn ɛls biɪŋ lɔɹd-fɪld ɪm wɪð ɪntɛns æŋzaɪəɾi. ən ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ əmaʊn ə sædnəs.

Still, the thought of someone else taking control - someone else being lord-filled him with intense anxiety. And a surprising amount of sadness.

"naʊ," feɪl sɛd, "stɑp jəɹ bɹuɾɪŋ. aɪ hæv ɡɹæn ɪntɛntʃənz fəɹ ðɪs ivnɪŋ." ʃi klæpt əɹ hænz laʊdli θɹi taɪmz, ən muvməns bɪɡæn bɪloʊ. sun, sɝvəns kɹɛstəd ðə hɪlsaɪd. pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əm əz pipəl ʃiɾ əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz, ə ɡɹup əz lɔɪəl tə hɝ əz tʃɑ feɪl.

"Now," Faile said, "stop your brooding. I have grand intentions for this evening." She clapped her hands loudly three times, and movements began below. Soon, servants crested the hillside. Perrin recognized them as people she'd appropriated from among the refugees, a group as loyal to her as Cha Faile.

ðeɪ kæɹid kænvəs, wɪtʃ ðeɪ spɹɛɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðən ðeɪ kʌvɝd ðət wɪð ə blæŋkət. ən wʌt wɑz ðəɾ i smɛl kʌmɪŋ ʌp fɹəm bɪloʊ? hæm?

They carried canvas, which they spread on the ground. Then they covered that with a blanket. And what was that he smelled coming up from below? Ham?

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs, feɪl?" hi æskt.

"What is this, Faile?" he asked.

"æt fɝst," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ əsum ðət jə hæd sʌmθɪŋ spɛʃəl plæn fəɹ əɹ ʃænəhɑɹ. aɪ ɡɹu nɝvəs wən jə dɪdn mɛnʃən ɪt, haʊɛvɝ, ən soʊ aɪ æskt. ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət jə də nɑt sɛləbɹeɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɑd ðoʊ ðəɾ ɪz."

"At first," she said, "I assumed that you had something special planned for our shanna'har. I grew nervous when you didn't mention it, however, and so I asked. It appears that you do not celebrate it in the Two Rivers, odd though that is."

"ʃænəhɑɹ?" pɛɹɪn æskt, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd.

"Shanna'har?" Perrin asked, scratching his head.

"ɪn ðə kʌmɪŋ wiks," feɪl sɛd, "wi wɪl əv bɪn mɛɹid wʌn jɪɹ. ðɪs ɪz əɹ fɝst ʃænəhɑɹ, əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ sɛləbɹeɪʃən." ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, wɑtʃɪŋ əz əɹ sɝvəns ɝeɪnʒd ə mil ɑn ðə blæŋkət. "ɪn sɑldɑiə, wi sɛləbɹeɪt ðə ʃænəhɑɹ itʃ jɪɹ ɪn ði ɝli sʌmɝ. ɪts ə fɛstəvəl tə mɑɹk ənʌðɝ jɪɹ təɡɛðɝ, ənʌðɝ jɪɹ wɪð niðɝ hʌzbənd nɔɹ waɪf fɔlən tə ðə tʃɹɑləks.

"In the coming weeks," Faile said, "we will have been married one year. This is our first shanna'har, our marriage celebration." She folded her arms, watching as her servants arranged a meal on the blanket. "In Saldaea, we celebrate the shanna'har each year in the early summer. It is a festival to mark another year together, another year with neither husband nor wife fallen to the Trollocs.

jʌŋ kʌpəlz ɑɹ toʊl tə seɪvɝ ðɛɹ fɝst ʃænəhɑɹ, mʌtʃ əz wʌn seɪvɝz ðə fɝs teɪst ʌv ə sʌkjəlɪn mil. əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ wɪl oʊnli bi nu tə əs wʌns." ðə sɝvəns leɪɾ aʊɾ ə mil, ɪnkluɾɪŋ sɛvɹəl ɡlæs boʊlz wɪð kændəlz ɪn ðɛm. feɪl dɪsmɪs ðə sɝvəns wɪð ə smaɪl ən ə weɪv, ən ðeɪ ɹitʃɹiɾəd daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɪl. feɪl hæɾ ɑbviəsli teɪkən kɛɹ tə meɪk ðə mil lʊk lævɪʃ. ðə blæŋkət wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd, pɝhæps teɪkən fɹəm ʃeɪɾoʊ spɔɪlz. ðə mil wɑz sɝvd ɑn sɪlvɝ pleɪts ən plæɾɝz, hæm ə bɛɾ ə bɔɪl bɑɹli ən keɪpɝz əkɹɔs ðə tɑp. ðəɹ wɑz ivən waɪn. feɪl stɛp kloʊsɝ tə hɪm. "aɪ ɹilaɪz ðət ðəɹ əz bɪn mʌtʃ, ðɪs jɪɹ, ðəɾ ɪz nɑt wɝθ seɪvɝɪŋ.

Young couples are told to savor their first shanna'har, much as one savors the first taste of a succulent meal. Our marriage will only be new to us once." The servants laid out a meal, including several glass bowls with candles in them. Faile dismissed the servants with a smile and a wave, and they retreated down the side of the hill. Faile had obviously taken care to make the meal look lavish. The blanket was embroidered, perhaps taken from Shaido spoils. The meal was served on silver plates and platters, ham a bed of boiled barley and capers across the top. There was even wine. Faile stepped closer to him. "I realize that there has been much, this year, that is not worth savoring.

meɪɾən, ðə pɹɑfət, ðət hɑɹʃ wɪntɝ. bʌɾ ɪf ðiz θɪŋz ɑɹ ðə kɑs fəɹ biɪŋ wɪð ju, pɛɹɪn, ðən aɪ wəd peɪ ðɛm fɹili ə dʌzən taɪmz oʊvɝ.

Maiden, the Prophet, that harsh winter. But if these things are the cost for being with you, Perrin, then I would pay them freely a dozen times over.

"ɪf ɔl wɝ wɛl, wi wəd spɛn ðɪs nɛks mʌnθ ɡɪvɪŋ ɡɪfs tə ɑn ənʌðɝ, əfɝmɪŋ əɹ lʌv, sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ əɹ fɝst sʌmɝ əz hʌzbən ən waɪf. aɪ daʊt wɪl əv ðə mʌnθ ʌv iz ðəɾ ɪz əɹ ɹaɪt, bʌɾ ət list wi ʃəd spɛn ən ɛndʒɔɪ ðɪs ivnɪŋ təɡɛðɝ."

"If all were well, we would spend this next month giving gifts to on another, affirming our love, celebrating our first summer as husband and wife. I doubt we will have the month of ease that is our right, but at least we should spend and enjoy this evening together."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ kæn, feɪl," hi sɛd. "ðə waɪtkloʊks, ðə skaɪ laɪt! ðə læs bæɾəl ɪtsɛlf ɪz ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ. ðə læs bæɾəl, feɪl! haʊ kən aɪ fist waɪl maɪ pipəl ɑɹ biɪŋ hɛld ʌndɝ θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛksəkjuʃən ən waɪl ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf meɪ daɪ?"

"I don't know if I can, Faile," he said. "The Whitecloaks, the sky Light! The Last Battle itself is almost here. The Last Battle, Faile! How can I feast while my people are being held under threat of execution and while the world itself may die?"

"ɪf ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ," feɪl sɛd, "ɪz ðɪs nɑt ðə taɪm wən ə mæn mʌs teɪk taɪm tə əpɹiʃieɪt wʌɾ i hæz? bɪfɔɹ ɪts ɔl teɪkən?"

"If the world itself is going to die," Faile said, "is this not the time when a man must take time to appreciate what he has? Before it is all taken?"

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, hɝ tʌtʃ soʊ sɑft. ʃi hædn ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs. dɪd ʃi wɑn ɪm tə jɛl? ɪt wɑz soʊ hɑɹd tə tɛl wən ʃi wɑntəɾ ən ɑɹɡjəmən ən wən ʃi dɪdnt. meɪbi ɛlaɪəs wəɾ əv ædvaɪs fəɹ hɪm.

Perrin hesitated. She laid a hand on his arm, her touch so soft. She hadn't raised her voice. Did she want him to yell? It was so hard to tell when she wanted an argument and when she didn't. Maybe Elyas would have advice for him.

"pliz," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɪlæks fəɹ wʌn ivnɪŋ. fəɹ mi."

"Please," she said softly. "Try to relax for one evening. For me."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd, leɪɪŋ ɪz hæn ɑn hɝz.

"All right," he said, laying his hand on hers.

ʃi lɛɾ ɪm tə ðə blæŋkəɾ ən ðeɪ sɛɾəld daʊn, saɪd baɪ saɪd bɪfɔɹ ði ɝeɪ ʌv sɪlvɝ dɪʃəz.

She led him to the blanket and they settled down, side by side before the array of silver dishes.

feɪl lɪt mɔɹ kændəlz ɔf ə ðə lɪt wʌnz ðə sɝvəns hæd lɛft. ðə naɪt wɑz tʃɪli - ðə klaʊdz sim tə dʒɹɔ sʌmɝ wɔɹmθ əweɪ. "waɪ də ðɪs aʊtsaɪd?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ænd nɑɾ ɪn əɹ tɛnt?"

Faile lit more candles off of the lit ones the servants had left. The night was chilly - the clouds seemed to draw summer warmth away. "Why do this outside?" Perrin said. "And not in our tent?"

"aɪ æsk tɑɹn wʌt jə də ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz fəɹ ʃænəhɑɹ" ʃi sɛd. "æn əz aɪ fɪɹd, aɪ lɝn ðət jə doʊn sɛləbɹeɪɾ ɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ɹɪli kwaɪt bækwɝd, jə ɹilaɪz - wɪl nid tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə kʌstəm, wʌns θɪŋz sɛɾəl daʊn. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, tæm sɛd ðət ðə kloʊsəs ðeɪ hæd wɑz sʌmθɪŋ i ən ɪz waɪf dɪd. wʌns ə jɪɹ, ðeɪ wəd pæk ʌp ə fʊl mil - əz ɪkstʃɹævəɡən əz ðeɪ kəɾ əfɔɹd - ən haɪk tə ə nu pleɪs ɪn ðə wʊdz. ðeɪ wəd daɪn ðəɹ ən spɛn ðə deɪ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ." ʃi snʌɡəld ʌp əɡɛns hɪm. "aʊɝ wɛɾɪŋ wɑz dʌn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz fæʃən, soʊ aɪ wɪʃt ðɪs deɪ tə bi æftɝ ðət fæʃən əz wɛl."

"I asked Tarn what you do in the Two Rivers for shannahar" she said. "And as I feared, I learned that you don't celebrate it. That is really quite backward, you realize - we'll need to change the custom, once things settle down. Regardless, Tam said that the closest they had was something he and his wife did. Once a year, they would pack up a full meal - as extravagant as they could afford - and hike to a new place in the woods. They would dine there and spend the day with one another." She snuggled up against him. "Our wedding was done in the Two Rivers fashion, so I wished this day to be after that fashion as well."

hi smaɪld. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɝliɝ əbdʒɛkʃənz ɪz tɛnʃən wɑz izɪŋ. ðə fud smɛld ɡʊd, ən ɪz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld, pɹɑmptɪŋ feɪl tə sɪɾ ʌp ən teɪk ɪz pleɪɾ ən hæn ɪt tə hɪm.

He smiled. Despite his earlier objections his tension was easing. The food smelled good, and his stomach growled, prompting Faile to sit up and take his plate and hand it to him.

hi dʌɡ ɪn. hi tʃɹaɪd tə kip ɪz mænɝz, bʌt ðə fud wɑz ɛksələnt, ən ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ deɪ.

He dug in. He tried to keep his manners, but the food was excellent, and it had been a long day.

hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɹɪpɪŋ ɪndə ðə hæm wɪð fɝɑsəɾi, ðoʊ hi tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk kɛɹ nɑt tə dʒɹɪp ɑn ðə fænsi blæŋkət.

He found himself ripping into the ham with ferocity, though he tried to take care not to drip on the fancy blanket.

feɪl eɪt mɔɹ sloʊli, ðə sɛn ʌv əmjuzmən mɪksɪŋ wɪð ðəɾ ə hɝ soʊp.

Faile ate more slowly, the scent of amusement mixing with that of her soap.

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn æskt, waɪpɪŋ ɪz maʊθ. ʃi wɑz lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ðə kæn-dlz ðət ðə sʌn wɑz fʊli daʊn. "ðɛɹz mʌtʃ ə ðə wʊlf ɪn ju, maɪ hʌzbənd."

"What?" Perrin asked, wiping his mouth. She was lit only by the can-dles that the sun was fully down. "There's much of the wolf in you, my husband."

hi fɹoʊz, noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðət hid bɪn lɪkɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi ɡɹaʊld ət sɛlf waɪpɪŋ əm ɪnstɛɾ ɑn ə næpkɪn. əz mʌtʃ əz i laɪkt wʊlvz, hi waʊdn ɪnvaɪɾ əm tə ðə dɪnɝ teɪbəl wɪð hɪm. "tu mʌtʃ ə ðə wʊlf ɪn mi," hi sɛd.

He froze, noticing that he'd been licking his fingers. He growled at self wiping them instead on a napkin. As much as he liked wolves, he woudn't invite them to the dinner table with him. "Too much of the wolf in me," he said.

"ju ɑɹ wʌt jə ɑɹ, maɪ hʌzbənd. ən aɪ hæpən tə lʌv wʌt jə ɑɹ, soʊ ðəɾ ɪz wɛl."

"You are what you are, my husband. And I happen to love what you are, so that is well."

hi kəntɪnjud tə tʃu ɑn ɪz kʌɾ ə ðə hæm. ðə naɪt wɑz kwaɪət, ðə sɝvəns hævɪŋ ɹitʃɹiɾəd fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ ðəɾ i kʊdn smɛl əɹ hɪɹ ðɛm. laɪkli feɪl hæd lɛft ɔɹɾɝz ðət ðeɪ wɝn tə bi dɪstɝbd, ən wɪð ðə tʃɹiz ət ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪlsaɪd, ðeɪ wʊdn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt biɪŋ əbzɝvd.

He continued to chew on his cut of the ham. The night was quiet, the servants having retreated far enough away that he couldn't smell or hear them. Likely Faile had left orders that they weren't to be disturbed, and with the trees at the base of the hillside, they wouldn't have to worry about being observed.

"feɪl," hi sɛd sɔfti, "ju nid tə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ dɪd waɪl jə wɝ kæptɪv. aɪ dɪd θɪŋz aɪ wɝid wəd tɝn mi ɪndə sʌmwʌn jə wəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɑnt. ɪt wɑzn oʊnli ðə dil wɪð ðə sintʃæn. ðəɹ wɝ pipəl ɪn ə sɪɾi, soʊ hæbɝ, ðəɾ aɪ kæn stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv. pipəl ðət meɪbi aɪ ʃəɾ əv hɛlpt. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃeɪɾoʊ, wɪð ɪz hænd - "

"Faile," he said softy, "you need to know what I did while you were captive. I did things I worried would turn me into someone you would no longer want. It wasn't only the deal with the Seanchan. There were people in a city, So Habor, that I can't stop thinking of. People that maybe I should have helped. And there was a Shaido, with his hand - "

"aɪ hɝɾ əbaʊt ðæt. ɪt simz ðət jə dɪd wʌt jə hæd tə."

"I heard about that. It seems that you did what you had to."

"aɪɾ əv ɡɔn mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ," pɛɹɪn ədmɪɾəd. "heɪɾɪŋ maɪsɛlf ɔl ðə weɪ. jə spoʊk ʌv ə lɔɹd biɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪzɪs lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bi mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd. wɛl, əl nɛvɝ bi ðət stʃɹɔŋ. nɑɾ ɪf jəɹ teɪkən."

"I'd have gone much farther," Perrin admitted. "Hating myself all the way. You spoke of a lord being strong enough to resist letting himself be manipulated. Well, I'll never be that strong. Not if you're taken."

"wi ʃæl əv tə meɪk sɝɾən aɪ doʊnt ɡɛt teɪkən."

"We shall have to make certain I don't get taken."

"ɪt kəd ɹuən mi, feɪl," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kəd hændəl. bʌɾ ɪf jə ɑɹ juzd əɡɛns mi, nʌθɪŋ wɪl mæɾɝ. aɪd də ɛniθɪŋ tə pɹətɛk ju, feɪl. ɛniθɪŋ."

"It could ruin me, Faile," he said softly. "Anything else, I think I could handle. But if you are used against me, nothing will matter. I'd do anything to protect you, Faile. Anything."

"pɝhæps jə ʃəd ɹæp mi ʌp ɪn sɑf klɔθ, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, ən tʌk mi əweɪ ɪn ə lɑkt ɹum." ɑdli, hɝ sɛnt wɑz nɑɾ əfɛndəd.

"Perhaps you should wrap me up in soft cloth, then," she said dryly, and tuck me away in a locked room." Oddly, her scent was not offended.

"aɪ wʊdn də ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ju noʊ aɪ wʊdnt. bʌt ðɪs minz aɪ hæv ə wiknəs, ə tɛɹəbəl wʌn. ðə taɪp ə liɾɝ kæn hæv."

"I wouldn't do that," Perrin said. "You know I wouldn't. But this means I have a weakness, a terrible one. The type a leader can't have."

ʃi snɔɹɾɪd. "ju θɪŋk ʌðɝ liɾɝz doʊn əv wiknəsəz, pɛɹɪn? ɛvɹi kɪŋ əɹ kwin ə sɑldɑiə hæz hæd ðɛɹ oʊn. nɪkiɔl daɪænætkə wɑz ə dʒɹʌŋkɝd, dɪspaɪt biɪŋ noʊn əz wʌn ʌv əɹ ɡɹeɪɾəst kɪŋz, ən bəlɛɹə mɛɹiɾ ən pʊɾ əɹ hʌzbən əweɪ fɔɹ taɪmz. hɝ hɑɹɾ ɔlweɪz dɪd lɛɾ əɹ tə tʃɹʌbəl. dʒoʊnəsim hæɾ ə sʌn huz ɡæmbəlɪŋ weɪz nɪɹli bɹɔɾ əɹ haʊs tə ɹuən, ən laɪənfɝd kʊdn kip ɪz tɛmpɝ ɪf tʃælənʒd. itʃ ən ɛvɹi wʌn wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt mɑnɑɹk. ən ɔl hæd ðɛɹ ʃɛɹ ʌv wiknəsəz."

She snorted. "You think other leaders don't have weaknesses, Perrin? every King or Queen of Saldaea has had their own. Nikiol Dianatkhah was a drunkard, despite being known as one of our greatest kings, and Belairah married and put her husband away four times. Her heart always did lead her to trouble. Jonasim had a son whose gambling ways nearly brought her House to ruin, and Lyonford couldn't keep his temper if challenged. Each and every one was a great monarch. And all had their share of Weaknesses."

pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə tʃu ɑn ɪz fud, θɔtfəl.

Perrin continued to chew on his food, thoughtful.

"ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz," feɪl sɛd, "wi hæv ə seɪɪŋ. 'ə pɑlɪʃt sɔɹd ɹɪflɛks ðə tʃɹuθ.' ə mæn kən kleɪm tə bi dɪlɪdʒən ɪn ɪz duɾiz, bʌɾ ɪf ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪzən pɑlɪʃt, jə noʊ ðət hiz bɪn aɪɾəl.

"In the Borderlands," Faile said, "we have a saying. 'A polished sword reflects the truth.' A man can claim to be diligent in his duties, but if his sword isn't polished, you know that he's been idle.

"wɛl, jəɹ sɔɹɾ ɪz bɹaɪt, maɪ hʌzbənd. ðiz læs fju wiks, jə kip seɪɪŋ ðət jə lɛd pʊɹli dʊɹɪŋ maɪ kæptɪvəɾi. juɾ əv mi bɪliv ðət jə lɛd ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp tə ɹuən ən dʌst! bʌt ðæts nɑt tʃɹu əɾ ɔl jə kɛpt əm foʊkəst; jə ɪnspaɪɝd ðɛm, meɪnteɪn ə stʃɹɔŋ pɹɛzəns ən kɛp ði ɛɹ ʌv ə lɔɹd."

"Well, your sword is bright, my husband. These last few weeks, you keep saying that you led poorly during my captivity. You'd have me believe that you led the entire camp to ruin and dust! But that's not true at all You kept them focused; you inspired them, maintained a strong presence and kept the air of a lord."

"bɹəleɪnz bɪhaɪn səm ə ðæt," hi sɛd. "aɪ hæf θɪŋk ðə wʊmən wʊɾə beɪð mi hɝsɛlf ɪf aɪd ɡɔn ənʌðɝ deɪ wɪθaʊt."

"Berelain's behind some of that," he said. "I half think the woman would have bathed me herself if I'd gone another day without."

"aɪm sɝɾən ðət wʊdn əv bɪn ɡʊd fəɹ ðə ɹumɝz," feɪl noʊɾəd dʒɹaɪli.

"I'm certain that wouldn't have been good for the rumors," Faile noted dryly.

"feɪl, aɪ - "

"Faile, I - "

"aɪl dil wɪð bɹəleɪn," feɪl sɛd. hɝ vɔɪs saʊndəd deɪnʒɝəs. "ðæts wʌn duɾi jə nidn dɪstʃɹæk jɝsɛlf wɪð."

"I'll deal with Berelain," Faile said. Her voice sounded dangerous. "That's one duty you needn't distract yourself with."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"aɪl dil wɪð hɝ," feɪl sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs mɔɹ fɝm. ɪt wɑz nɑt waɪz tə tʃælənʒ əɹ wən ʃi smɛl ðət weɪ, nɑɾ ənlɛs i wɑntəd tə stɑɹɾ ə fʊl ɑɹɡjəmənt. ʃi sɔfənd, teɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ baɪɾ ə bɑɹli. "wɛn aɪ sɛd jə wɝ laɪk ə wʊlf, maɪ hʌzbənd, aɪ wɑzn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə weɪ jə it. aɪ wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə weɪ jə ɡɪv jəɹ ətɛnʃən. jə ɑɹ dʒɹɪvən. ɡɪvən ə pɹɑbləm tə sɑlv, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɡɹænd, ən jəl si ɪt dʌn.

"I'll deal with her," Faile said, her voice more firm. It was not wise to challenge her when she smelled that way, not unless he wanted to start a full argument. She softened, taking another bite of barley. "When I said you were like a wolf, my husband, I wasn't talking about the way you eat. I was talking about the way you give your attention. You are driven. Given a problem to solve, no matter how grand, and you will see it done.

"kæn jə ʌndɝstænd? ðæts ə wʌndɝfəl tʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ə liɾɝ- ɪts ɪɡzækli wʌt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪl nid. əsumɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ðət juv ə waɪf tə kɛɹ fəɹ səm ə ðə smɔlɝ ɪʃuz." ʃi fɹaʊnd.

"Can't you understand? That's a wonderful trait in a leader- It is exactly what the Two Rivers will need. Assuming, of course, that you have a wife to care for some of the smaller issues." She frowned.

"aɪ wɪʃ jud spoʊkən tə mi əbaʊt ðə bænɝ bɪfɔɹ bɝnɪŋ ɪt. ɪɾəl bi dɪfəkəl tə ɹeɪz ɪɾ əɡɛn wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ fulɪʃ."

"I wish you'd spoken to me about the banner before burning it. It will be difficult to raise it again without looking foolish."
