"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə ɹeɪz ɪɾ əɡɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðæts waɪ aɪ hæɾ əm bɝn ɪt."

"I don't want to raise it again," Perrin said. "That's why I had them burn it."

"bʌt waɪ?"

"But why?"

hi tʊk ənʌðɝ baɪɾ ə hɪz hæm, pɔɪntɪdli nɑt wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. ʃi smɛl kjʊɹiəs, ɔlmoʊs dɛspɝətli soʊ.

He took another bite of his ham, pointedly not watching her. She smelled curious, almost desperately so.

aɪ kæn lid ðɛm, hi θɔt. nɑɾ əntɪl aɪ noʊ ɪf aɪ kən mæstɝ ðə wʊlf haʊ kəɾ i ɪkspleɪn?

I can't lead them, he thought. Not until I know if I can master the wolf How could he explain?

ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ i fɪɹd ðə weɪ ɪt tʊk kəntʃɹoʊl wən i fɔt, wən i wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ tu bædli?

Explain that he feared the way it took control when he fought, when he wanted something too badly?

hi wəd nɑt ɹɪd hɪmsɛlf ə ðə wʊlvz; ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm tu mʌtʃ ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm. bʌt wɛɹ wəɾ i liv ɪz pipəl, wɛɹ wəɾ i liv feɪl, ɪf i lɔs hɪmsɛlf tə wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm?

He would not rid himself of the wolves; they had become too much a part of him. But where would he leave his people, where would he leave Faile, if he lost himself to what was inside of him?

hi əɡɛn ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə dɝɾi kɹitʃɝ, wʌns ə mæn, lɑkt ɪn ə keɪdʒ-ðɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ɪn ðɪs wʌn ðət ɹɪmɛmbɝz biɪŋ ə mæn . . .

He again remembered a dirty creature, once a man, locked in a cage-There is nothing left in this one that remembers being a man . . .

"maɪ hʌzbənd," feɪl sɛd, ɹɛstɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. "pliz." ʃi smɛld ə peɪn. ðət twɪstəɾ ɪz hɑɹɾ əbaʊt. "ɪɾ əz tə də wɪð ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wʌt? pɛɹɪn, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ sɛd - "

"My husband," Faile said, resting a hand on his arm. "Please." She smelled of pain. That twisted his heart about. "It has to do with those Whitecloaks," Perrin said. "What? Perrin, I thought I said - "

"ɪɾ əz tə du," pɛɹɪn sɛd fɝmli, "wɪð wʌt hæpən tə mi ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ mɛt wɪð ðɛm. ən wʌɾ aɪd bɪɡʌn tə dɪskʌvɝ ɪn ðə deɪz bɪfɔɹ." feɪl fɹaʊnd. "aɪv toʊl jə ðəɾ aɪ kɪl tu waɪtkloʊks," hi sɛd. "bɪfɔɹ aɪ mɛt ju."

"It has to do," Perrin said firmly, "with what happened to me the first time I met with them. And what I'd begun to discover in the days before." Faile frowned. "I've told you that I killed two Whitecloaks," he said. "Before I met you."

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"sɛɾəl bæk," hi sɛd. "ju nid tə noʊ ðə hoʊl stɔɹi." ən soʊ hi toʊl hɝ. hɛzɪɾəntli ət fɝst, bʌt ðə wɝdz sun ɡɹu iziɝ. hi spoʊk ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ən ə ðɛɹ ɡɹup biɪŋ skæɾɝd. ʌv ɛɡwin lɛɾɪŋ ɪm teɪk ðə lɛd, pɝhæps ðə fɝs taɪm hid bɪn fɔɹs tə də ðæt.

"Settle back," he said. "You need to know the whole story." And so he told her. Hesitantly at first, but the words soon grew easier. He spoke of Shadar Logoth, and of their group being scattered. Of Egwene letting him take the lead, perhaps the first time he'd been forced to do that.

hiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi toʊld əɹ ə hɪz miɾɪŋ wɪð ɛlaɪəs. ʃi nu mʌtʃ əbaʊt pɛɹɪn, θɪŋz ðət hid nɛvɝ toʊld ɛniwʌn ɛls, θɪŋz hid nɛvɝ ivən spoʊkən ʌv wɪð ɛlaɪəs. ʃi nu əbaʊt ðə wʊlf. ʃi nu ðəɾ i fɪɹd hid luz hɪmsɛlf.

He'd already told her of his meeting with Elyas. She knew much about Perrin, things that he'd never told anyone else, things he'd never even spoken of with Elyas. She knew about the wolf. She knew that he feared he'd lose himself.

bʌt ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ i fɛlt ɪn bæɾəl. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt hæd fɛlt laɪk tə kɪl ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks, tə teɪs ðɛɹ blʌd - iðɝ ɪn ɪz oʊn maʊθ, əɹ θɹu hɪz lɪŋk wɪð ðə wʊlvz. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk tə bi kənsum baɪ æŋɡɝ, fɪɹ ən dɛspɝeɪʃən wən ʃid bɪn teɪkən. ðiz wɝ ðə θɪŋz i hɔltɪŋli ɪkspleɪnd.

But she didn't know what he felt in battle. She didn't know what it had felt like to kill those Whitecloaks, to taste their blood - either in his own mouth, or through his link with the wolves. She didn't know what it had been like to be consumed by anger, fear and desperation when she'd been taken. These were the things he haltingly explained.

hi toʊld əɹ ə ðə fɹɛnzi hid ɡɔn ɪndə wən sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. hi spoʊk ə noʊm ən wʌɾ i fɪɹd wəd hæpən tə hɪm. ən ə haʊ ɪt ɹɪleɪɾɪd tə haʊ hi æktəd wən i fɔt.

He told her of the frenzy he'd gone into when searching for her in the wolf dream. He spoke of Noam and what he feared would happen to him. And of how it related to how he acted when he fought.

feɪl lɪsənd, sɪɾɪŋ kwaɪətli ətɑp ðə hɪltɑp, ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ lɛɡz, lɪt baɪ kændəllaɪt.

Faile listened, sitting quietly atop the hilltop, arms wrapped around her legs, lit by candlelight.

hɝ sɛns wɝ səbdud. pɝhæps i ʃʊɾə hɛl səm θɪŋz bæk. noʊ wʊmən wɑntəd tə noʊ wʌɾ ə bist əɹ hʌzbən bɪkeɪm wən i kɪld, dɪd ʃi? bʌt naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz spikɪŋ, hi wɑntəd tə bi ɹɪɾ ə hɪz sikɹəts. hi wɑz taɪɝɾ ə ðɛm.

Her scents were subdued. Perhaps he should have held some things back. No woman wanted to know what a beast her husband became when he killed, did she? But now that he was speaking, he wanted to be rid of his secrets. He was tired of them.

itʃ wɝd spoʊkən meɪɾ ɪm ɹɪlæks mɔɹ. ɪt dɪd wʌt ðə mil -  tʌtʃɪŋ ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn -  hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə. ɪn tɛlɪŋ əɹ ə hɪz stʃɹʌɡəlz, hi fɛl səm ə hɪz bɝɾən lɪft.

Each word spoken made him relax more. It did what the meal -  touching though it had been -  hadn't been able to. In telling her of his struggles, he felt some of his burden lift.

hi fɪnɪʃt baɪ spikɪŋ ə hɑpɝ. hi wɑzn sɝɾən waɪ hid seɪv ðə wʊlf fəɹ læst; hɑpɝ wɑz pɑɹɾ ə mʌtʃ pɛɹɪn hæd toʊl bɪfɔɹ - ðə waɪtkloʊks, ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt tə ɹɪzɝv hɑpɝ əntɪl ði ɛnd, soʊ hi dɪd.

He finished by speaking of Hopper. He wasn't certain why he'd saved the wolf for last; Hopper was part of much Perrin had told before - the Whitecloaks, the wolf dream. But it felt right to reserve Hopper until the end, so he did.

əz i fɪnɪʃt, hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə fleɪm ʌv wʌn ə ðə kændəlz. tu ʌv əm hæd ɡɔn aʊt, livɪŋ ʌðɝz stɪl tə flɪkɝ. ðət wɑzn dɪm laɪt tə hɪz aɪz. hi hæd tʃɹʌbəl ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌt ðə deɪz hæd bɪn laɪk wən ɪz sɛnsɪz hæd bɪn əz wik əz ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi mænz.

As he finished, he stared at the flame of one of the candles. Two of them had gone out, leaving others still to flicker. That wasn't dim light to his eyes. He had trouble remembering what the days had been like when his senses had been as weak as an ordinary man's.

feɪl lin əɡɛns hɪm, ɹæpɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɝ. "θæŋk ju" ʃi sɛd.

Faile leaned against him, wrapping his arm around her. "Thank you" she said.

hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə dip saɪ, linɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ðə stʌmp bɪhaɪn hɪm, filɪŋ əɹ wɔɹmθ.

He let out a deep sigh, leaning back against the stump behind him, feeling her warmth.

"aɪ wɑnə tɛl jə əbaʊt meɪɾən," ʃi sɛd.

"I want to tell you about Maiden," she said.

"ju doʊn əv tə," hi sɛd. "dʒʌs kəz aɪ - "

"You don't have to," he said. "Just because I - "

"hʌʃ. aɪ wɑz kwaɪət waɪl jə spoʊk. ɪts maɪ tɝn."

"Hush. I was quiet while you spoke. It's my turn."

"ɔl ɹaɪt."

"All right."

ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn wɝiɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə hɪɹ əbaʊt meɪɾən. hi leɪ wɪð ɪz bæk tə ðə stʌmp, skaɪ kɹæklɪŋ wɪð ɛnɝdʒi əbʌv, ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ ʌv ənɹævəlɪŋ, waɪl ɪz waɪf spoʊk ə biɪŋ kæptʃɝɾ ən biɾən. jɛɾ ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊst ɑdli ɹɪlæksɪŋ θɪŋz hiɾ ɛvɝ ɪkspɪɹiənst.

It should have been worrying for him to hear about Maiden. He lay with his back to the stump, sky crackling with energy above, the Pattern itself in danger of unraveling, while his wife spoke of being captured and beaten. Yet it was one of the most oddly relaxing things he'd ever experienced.

ði ɪvɛns ɪn ðət sɪɾi hæd bɪn ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ, meɪbi ivən ɡʊd fəɹ hɝ. ðoʊ hi wɑz æŋɡɝɾ ət hɪɹɪŋ haʊ sɪvænə hæd tʃɹʌs feɪl ʌp neɪkəɾ ən lɛft əɹ oʊvɝnaɪt. sʌmdeɪ hid hʌn ðət wʊmən daʊn.

The events in that city had been important to her, maybe even good for her. Though he was angered at hearing how Sevanna had trussed Faile up naked and left her overnight. Someday he'd hunt that woman down.

nɑt tədeɪ, haʊɛvɝ. tədeɪ hi hæɾ ɪz waɪf ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz, ən əɹ stʃɹɔŋ vɔɪs wɑz ə kʌmfɝt. hi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪzd ʃi wʊɾə plæn əɹ oʊn ɪskeɪp. ɪn fækt, lɪsnɪŋ tə hɝ kɛɹfəl pɹɛpɝeɪʃən, hi bɪɡæn tə fil ə ful. ʃid bɪn wɝid ðət hid ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf kɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɛskju hɝ -  ʃi dɪdn seɪ ɪt, bʌɾ i kəɾ ɪnfɝ ɪt. haʊ wɛl ʃi nu hɪm.

Not today, however. Today he had his wife in his arms, and her strong voice was a comfort. He should have realized she would have planned her own escape. In fact, listening to her careful preparation, he began to feel a fool. She'd been worried that he'd get himself killed trying to rescue her -  she didn't say it, but he could infer it. How well she knew him.

feɪl lɛf səm θɪŋz aʊt. hi dɪdn maɪnd. feɪl wəd bi laɪk ə pɛn ən keɪdʒd ænəməl wɪθaʊɾ əɹ sikɹəts. hi ɡɑɾ ə ɡʊd hɪn ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ, ðoʊ. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðət bɹʌðɝləs u hæd kæptʃɝd hɝ, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt feɪlz plænz tə tʃɹɪk ðə mæn ən ɪz fɹɛnz ɪndə hɛlpɪŋ əɹ ɪskeɪp. pɝhæps ʃid fɛlt ə fɑndnəs fəɹ hɪm, ən dɪdnt wɪʃ pɛɹɪn tə ɹəɡɹɛt kɪlɪŋ hɪm.

Faile left some things out. He didn't mind. Faile would be like a penned and caged animal without her secrets. He got a good hint of what she was hiding, though. It was something to do with that Brotherless who had captured her, something about Faile's plans to trick the man and his friends into helping her escape. Perhaps she'd felt a fondness for him, and didn't wish Perrin to regret killing him.

ðət wɑznt nɛsəsɛɹi. ðoʊz bɹʌðɝləs hæd bɪn wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ətækt ən kɪl mɛn ʌndɝ pɛɹɪnz pɹətɛkʃən. noʊ ækt ə kaɪndnəs wəd ɹɪdim ðæt. ðeɪ dɪzɝv ðɛɹ dɛθs.

That wasn't necessary. Those Brotherless had been with the Shaido, and they had attacked and killed men under Perrin's protection. No act of kindness would redeem that. They deserved their deaths.

ðət ɡeɪv ɪm pɔz. ðə waɪtkloʊks pɹɑbli sɛd vɛɹi sɪməlɝ θɪŋz əbaʊt hɪm. bʌt ðə waɪtkloʊks hæɾ ətæk fɝst.

That gave him pause. The Whitecloaks probably said very similar things about him. But the Whitecloaks had attacked first.

ʃi fɪnɪʃt. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi leɪt, naʊ, ən pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt oʊvɝ tə ə bʌndəl ðət feɪlz sɝvəns hæd bɹɔɾ ʌp, pʊlɪŋ aʊɾ ə blæŋkət.

She finished. It was very late, now, and Perrin reached over to a bundle that Faile's servants had brought up, pulling out a blanket.

"wɛl?" feɪl æskt əz i sɛɾəld bæk, pʊɾɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ əɡɛn.

"Well?" Faile asked as he settled back, putting his arm around her again.

"aɪm sɝpɹaɪz ðət jə dɪdnt ɡɪmi ən ɪɹfəl fəɹ bæɹəlɪŋ ɪn laɪk ə waɪl bʊl ən stɑmpɪŋ ɔl oʊvɝ jəɹ plænz."

"I'm surprised that you didn't give me an earful for barreling in like a wild bull and stomping all over your plans."

ðət meɪɾ əɹ smɛl sæɾəsfaɪd. ɪt wɑzn ði ɪmoʊʃən hiɾ ɪkspɛktəd, bʌt hid lɔŋ əɡoʊ stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪfɝ ðə weɪz ʌv wɪmənz θɔt.

That made her smell satisfied. It wasn't the emotion he'd expected, but he'd long ago stopped trying to decipher the ways of women's thought.

"aɪ ɔlmoʊs bɹɔt ðə mæɾɝ ʌp tənaɪt," feɪl sɛd, "soʊ ðət wi kəɾ əv ə pɹɑpɝ ɑɹɡjəmən ən ə pɹɑpɝ ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən."

"I almost brought the matter up tonight," Faile said, "so that we could have a proper argument and a proper reconciliation."

"waɪ dɪdn ju?"

"Why didn't you?"

"aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ðɪs naɪt ʃəd bi dʌn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz weɪ."

"I decided that this night should be done in the Two Rivers way."

"æn jə θɪŋk hʌzbənz ən waɪvz doʊn ɑɹɡju ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?" hi æskt, əmjuzd.

"And you think husbands and wives don't argue in the Two Rivers?" he asked, amused.

"wɛl, pɝhæps ðeɪ du. bʌt ju, hʌzbənd, ɔlweɪz sim ənkʌmftəɹbəl wən wi jɛl. aɪm vɛɹi ɡlæd juv bɪɡʌn tə stæn ʌp fəɹ jɝsɛlf, əz ɪz pɹɑpɝ. bʌɾ aɪ hæv æsk mʌtʃ fɹəm jə tə ədæp tə maɪ weɪz. aɪ θɔt, tənaɪt, aɪ wəd tʃɹaɪ tə ədæp tə jʊɹz."

"Well, perhaps they do. But you, husband, always seem uncomfortable when we yell. I'm very glad you've begun to stand up for yourself, as is proper. But I have asked much from you to adapt to my ways. I thought, tonight, I would try to adapt to yours."

ðoʊz wɝ wɝdz ðəɾ i hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə hɪɹ fɹəm feɪl. ɪt sim ðə moʊs pɝsənəl θɪŋ ʃi kəɾ ɛvɝ əv ɡɪvən hɪm. ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋli, hi fɛl tɪɹz ɪn ɪz aɪz, ən i pʊld əɹ taɪt.

Those were words that he had never expected to hear from Faile. It seemed the most personal thing she could ever have given him. Embarrassingly, he felt tears in his eyes, and he pulled her tight.

"naʊ," ʃi sɛd, "aɪm nɑɾ ə dɑsəl ʃip, maɪn ju."

"Now," she said, "I'm not a docile sheep, mind you."

"aɪ wəd nɛvɝ θɪŋk ðæt," hi sɛd. "nɛvɝ."

"I would never think that," he said. "Never."

ʃi smɛl sæɾəsfaɪd.

She smelled satisfied.

"aɪm sɑɹi aɪ dɪdnt ɡɪv mʌtʃ θɔt tə jə ɪskeɪpɪŋ ɑn jəɹ oʊn," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I'm sorry I didn't give much thought to you escaping on your own," Perrin said.

"aɪ fɝɡɪv ju."

"I forgive you."

hi lʊk daʊn ət hɝ, ðoʊz bjuɾəfəl dɑɹk aɪz ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə kændəllaɪt. "dʌz ðɪs min wi kən əv ðə ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən wɪθaʊt ði ɑɹɡjəmənt?"

He looked down at her, those beautiful dark eyes reflecting the candlelight. "Does this mean we can have the reconciliation without the argument?"

ʃi smaɪld. "aɪ wɪl əlaʊ ɪt, ðɪs wʌns. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, ðə sɝvəns əv stʃɹɪkt ɔɹɾɝz tə ɛnʃʊɹ əɹ sɑlətud."

She smiled. "I will allow it, this once. And, of course, the servants have strict orders to ensure our solitude."

hi kɪs hɝ. ɪt fɛl soʊ vɛɹi ɹaɪt, ən i nu ðət ðə wɝiz hid hæd - ən ði ɔkwɝdnəs ðət hæd bɪn bɪtwin əm sɪns meɪɾən -  wɝ ɡɔn. wɛðɝ ɪt hæd bɪn sʌmθɪŋ ɹil əɹ sʌmθɪŋ i ɪmædʒənd, ɪt hæd pæst.

He kissed her. It felt so very right, and he knew that the worries he'd had - and the awkwardness that had been between them since Maiden -  were gone. Whether it had been something real or something he imagined, it had passed.

hi hæd feɪl bæk, tʃɹuli ən kəmplitli.

He had Faile back, truly and completely.


tʃæptɝ pɑɹɾɪŋz, ən ə miɾɪŋ



CHAPTER Partings, and a Meeting

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ ðə ɡoʊləm ətæk, mæt woʊk fɹəm dʒɹimz ɹɑɾən əz læs mʌnθs ɛɡz, filɪŋ stɪf ən eɪkɪŋ. hi hæd spɛn ðə naɪt slipɪŋ ɪn ə hɑloʊ hid faʊn bɪniθ ɑlʌdʒɹəz səplaɪ wæɡən. hi hæd tʃoʊzən ðə loʊkeɪʃən baɪ ɹændəm tʃæns, juzɪŋ ɪz daɪs.

The morning after the gholam attack, Mat woke from dreams rotten as last month's eggs, feeling stiff and aching. He had spent the night sleeping in a hollow he'd found beneath Aludra's supply wagon. He had chosen the location by random chance, using his dice.

hi klaɪmd aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə wæɡən, stændɪŋ ən ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, filɪŋ ɪt pɑp. blʌɾi æʃəz. wʌn ə ðə bɛs θɪŋz əbaʊt hævɪŋ mʌni wɑz nɑt hævɪŋ tə slip ɪn dɪtʃəz. ðəɹ wɝ bɛɡɝz u spɛnt naɪts bɛɾɝ ðən ðɪs.

He climbed out from under the wagon, standing and rolling his shoulder, feeling it pop. Bloody ashes. One of the best things about having money was not having to sleep in ditches. There were beggars who spent nights better than this.

ðə wæɡən smɛld ə sʌlfɝ ən paʊɾɝz. hi wɑz tɛmptəd tə pik ʌndɝ ði ɔɪl tɑɹp ðət stʃɹɛtʃt oʊvɝ ðə bæk ʌv, bʌt ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ pɔɪnt. ɑlʌdʒɹə ən əɹ paʊɾɝz wɝ ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə dʒɹæɡənz pɝfɔɹmd, mæt dɪd nɑt maɪnd nɑt noʊɪŋ haʊ ðeɪ wɝkt. wɛl, hi dɪd nɑt maɪn ɪt mʌtʃ. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪsk ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ hɝ.

The wagon smelled of sulphur and powders. He was tempted to peek under the oiled tarp that stretched over the back of, but there would be no point. Aludra and her powders were incomprehensible. So long as the dragons performed, Mat did not mind not knowing how they worked. Well, he did not mind it much. Not enough to risk irritating her.

ʃi wɑz nɑt ðəɹ ət ðə wæɡən, fɔɹtʃənətli fəɹ mæt. ʃi wəd kəmpleɪn əɾ ɪm əɡɛn fəɹ nɑt hævɪŋ ɡɑɾən əɹ ə bɛlfndɝ. ʃi sim tə θɪŋk ɪm əɹ oʊn pɝsənəl mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪ. ən ənɹuli wʌn, hu ɹəfjuz tə də hɪz dʒɑb pɹɑpɝli. moʊst wɪmən hæd moʊməns laɪk ðæt.

She was not there at the wagon, fortunately for Mat. She would complain at him again for not having gotten her a bellfounder. She seemed to think him her own personal messenger boy. An unruly one, who refused to do his job properly. Most women had moments like that.

hi wɔk θɹu kæmp, bɹʌʃɪŋ bɪts ə stʃɹɔ fɹəm ɪz hɛɹ. hi ɔlmoʊst wɛn sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ləpɪn tə hæv ɪm dʒɹɔ ə bæθ, əntɪl i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ləpɪn wɑz dɛd. blʌɾi æʃəz! pʊɹ mæn.

He walked through camp, brushing bits of straw from his hair. He almost went searching for Lopin to have him draw a bath, until he remembered that Lopin was dead. Bloody ashes! Poor man.

θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt pʊɹ ləpɪn pʊt mæt ɪn ən ivən mɔɹ daʊɝ muɾ əz i aɪk təwɔɹd wɛɹ hid faɪn səm bɹɛkfəst. dʒulɪn faʊn ɪm fɝst. ðə ʃɔɹt tɛɹən θif-kætʃɝ wɔɹ ɪz flæt-tɑp kɑnɪkəl hæɾ ən dɑɹk blu "mæt," hi sɛd. "ɪz ɪt tʃɹu? juv ɡɪvən pɝmɪʃən fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə taʊɝ?"

Thinking about poor Lopin put Mat in an even more dour mood as he Iked toward where he'd find some breakfast. Juilin found him first. The short Tairen thief-catcher wore his flat-topped conical hat and dark blue "Mat," he said. "Is it true? You've given permission for the Aes Sedai to go back to the Tower?"

"ðeɪ dɪdnt nid maɪ pɝmɪʃən," mæt sɛd, wɪnsɪŋ. ɪf ðə wɪmən hɝɾ ɪt sɛd ðət weɪ, ðeɪ wəd tæn ɪz haɪɾ ən meɪk sæɾəl lɛðɝ fɹəm ɪt. "aɪm plænɪŋ tə ɡɪv əm hɔɹsəz, ðoʊ."

"They didn't need my permission," Mat said, wincing. If the women heard it said that way, they would tan his hide and make saddle leather from it. "I'm planning to give them horses, though."

"ðeɪ hæv əm ɔlɹɛɾi," dʒulɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə pɪkət laɪnz. "sɛd jə ɡeɪv əm pɝmɪʃən."

"They have them already," Juilin said, looking in the direction of the picket lines. "Said you gave them permission."

mæt saɪd. hɪz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld, bʌt fud wəɾ əv tə weɪt. hi wɔk təwɔɹd ðə pɪkət laɪnz; hi wəd nid tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd nɑt meɪk ɔf wɪð ɪz bɛst stɑk.

Mat sighed. His stomach growled, but food would have to wait. He walked toward the picket lines; he would need to make sure the Aes Sedai did not make off with his best stock.

"aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ aɪ maɪt ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm," dʒulɪn sɛd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ mæt. "teɪk θɛɹə tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"I've been thinking I might go with them," Juilin said, joining Mat. "Take Thera to Tar Valon."

"jɔɹ wɛlkəm tə liv ɛni taɪm," mæt sɛd. "aɪ woʊn hoʊl jə hɪɹ." dʒulɪn wɑz ə ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fɛloʊ. ə lɪɾəl stɪf ət taɪmz. wɛl, vɛɹi stɪf. dʒulɪn kəd meɪk ə waɪtkloʊk lʊk ɹɪlækst. hi wɑz nɑt ðə taɪp jə wɑntəd tə teɪk wɪð jə dɪsɪŋ; hi wəd spɛn ðə naɪt skaʊlɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə tævɝn ən mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kɹaɪmz ðeɪ hæd sɝɾənli kəmɪɾəd. bʌɾ i wɑz ɹɪlaɪəbəl, ən ə ɡʊd hæn tə hæv ɪn ə pɪntʃ.

"You're welcome to leave any time," Mat said. "I won't hold you here." Juilin was a good enough fellow. A little stiff at times. Well, very stiff. Juilin could make a Whitecloak look relaxed. He was not the type you wanted to take with you dicing; he would spend the night scowling at everyone in the tavern and muttering about the crimes they had certainly committed. But he was reliable, and a good hand to have in a pinch.

"aɪ wɑnə ɡɛt bæk tə tɛɹ," dʒulɪn sɛd. "bʌt ðə sintʃæn wəd bi soʊ kloʊz, ən θɛɹə ... ɪt wɝiz hɝ. ʃi dʌzn mʌtʃ laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv tɑɹ vəlɑn iðɝ, bʌt wi doʊn əv mɛni tʃɔɪsəz, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹɑməs ðəɾ ɪf aɪ keɪm wɪð ðɛm, ðeɪd ɡɛt mi wɝk ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"I want to get back to Tear," Juilin said. "But the Seanchan would be so close, and Thera ... It worries her. She doesn't much like the idea of Tar Valon either, but we don't have many choices, and the Aes Sedai promised that if I came with them, they'd get me work in Tar Valon."

"soʊ, ðɪs ɪz pɑɹɾɪŋ, ðɛn?" mæt sɛd, stɑpɪŋ ən tɝnɪŋ tə hɪm.

"So, this is parting, then?" Mat said, stopping and turning to him.

"fɔɹ naʊ," dʒulɪn sɛd. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hænd. mæt tʊk ɪɾ ən ʃʊk, ən ðən ðə θif-kætʃɝ wɑz ɔf tə ɡæðɝ ɪz θɪŋz ən ɪz wʊmən.

"For now," Juilin said. He hesitated, then held out his hand. Mat took it and shook, and then the thief-catcher was off to gather his things and his woman.

mæt θɔt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪn ən hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə kʊk tɛnt. dʒulɪn wəd sloʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɹɑbli, ən i wɑntəd tə fɛtʃ sʌmθɪŋ.

Mat thought for a moment, then changed his mind and headed for the cook tent. Juilin would slow the Aes Sedai, probably, and he wanted to fetch something.

ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ, hi ɝaɪvd ət ðə pɪkət laɪnz fɛɾ ən kæɹiɪŋ ə klɔθ-ɹæp bʌndəl ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd, ʌv kɔɹs, kɹieɪɾəd ən ɪnɔɹɾənətli lɑɹdʒ kæɹəvæn aʊɾ ə səm ə hɪz bɛs hɔɹsəz. tɛslɪn ən dʒoʊlin ɔlsoʊ sim tə hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ kəd kəmændɪɹ səm pæk ɑni-mælz ən səm soʊlʒɝz tə də ðə loʊɾɪŋ. mæt saɪɾ ən wɔkt ɪndə ðə mɛs, tʃɛkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɔɹsəz.

A short time later, he arrived at the picket lines fed and carrying a cloth-wrapped bundle under his arm. The Aes Sedai had, of course, created an inordinately large caravan out of some of his best horses. Teslyn and Joline also seemed to have decided they could commandeer some pack ani-mals and some soldiers to do the loading. Mat sighed and walked into the mess, checking over the horses.

dʒoʊlin sæɾ ɑn mʊŋɡloʊ, ə mɛɹ ə tɛɹən stɑk ðət hæd bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn ə ðə mɛn mæt hæd lɔst ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp ðə sintʃæn. ðə mɔɹ ɹɪzɝvd idɛzinə hæd maʊntəd faɪɹɪsp, ən wɑz ɡlænsɪŋ əkeɪʒən-ælaɪ ət tu wɪmən u stʊd tə ðə saɪd. dɑɹk-skɪn bɛθəmən ən peɪl, jɛloʊ-hɛɹd sɛɾə wɝ fɔɹmɝ sʌldəm.

Joline sat on Moonglow, a mare of Tairen stock that had belonged to one of the men Mat had lost in the fighting to escape the Seanchan. The more reserved Edesina had mounted Firewisp, and was glancing occasion-ally at two women who stood to the side. Dark-skinned Bethamin and pale, yellow-haired Seta were former sul'dam.

ðə sintʃæn wɪmən tʃɹaɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd tə lʊk əluf əz ðə ɡɹup ɡæθ-ɛɝɛd. mæt sɔntɝɾ ʌp tə ðɛm.

The Seanchan women tried very hard to look aloof as the group gath-ered. Mat sauntered up to them.

"haɪnəs," sɛɾə sɛd, "ɪɾ ɪz tʃɹu? jəɹ gɑnə əlaʊ ðiz tə ɹoʊm fɹi ʌv ju?"

"Highness," Seta said, "it is true? You're going to allow these to roam free of you?"

"bɛs tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm," mæt sɛd, wɪnsɪŋ əɾ əɹ tʃɔɪs ə taɪɾəlz fəɹ hɪm. dɪd ðeɪv tə θɹoʊ ɝaʊn sətʃ wɝdz ðət laɪk ðeɪ wɝ wʊɾən pɛniz? ɛniweɪ, ðə tu sintʃæn wɪmən hæd tʃeɪnʒd ə ɡɹeɪt dil sɪns bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɹup, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl sim tə faɪn ɪɾ ɑd ðət mæt dɪd nɑt wɪʃ tə juz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz wɛpənz. "du jə wɑnə ɡoʊ, əɹ dʒju wɑnə steɪ?"

"Best to be rid of them," Mat said, wincing at her choice of titles for him. Did they have to throw around such words that like they were wooden pennies? Anyway, the two Seanchan women had changed a great deal since beginning with the group, but they still seemed to find it odd that Mat did not wish to use the Aes Sedai as weapons. "Do you want to go, or do you want to stay?"

"wi wɪl ɡoʊ," bɛθəmən sɛd fɝmli. ʃi wɑz dɪtɝmən tə lɝn, ɪt simd, "jɛs,' sɛɾə sɛd, "ðoʊ aɪ səmtaɪmz θɪŋk ɪt maɪt bi bɛɾɝ tə sɪmpli lɛɾ əs daɪ, əz əpoʊz tə . .

"We will go," Bethamin said firmly. She was determined to learn, it seemed, "Yes,' Seta said, "though I sometimes think it might be better to simply let us die, as opposed to . .

. wɛl, wʌt wi ɑɹ, wʌt wi ɹɛpɹəzɛnt, minz ðət wəɹ ə deɪnʒɝ tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ."

. Well, what we are, what we represent, means that we are a danger to the Empire."

mæt nɑɾəd. "tuɑn ɪz ə sʌldəm" hi sɛd.

Mat nodded. "Tuon is a sul'dam" he said.

ðə tu wɪmən lʊk daʊn.

The two women looked down.

"ɡoʊ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ," mæt sɛd. "aɪl ɡɪv jə jəɹ oʊn hɔɹsəz, soʊ jə doʊn əv tə ɹɪlaɪ ɑn ðɛm. lɝn tə tʃænəl. ðæɾəl bi mɔɹ juz ðən daɪɪŋ. meɪbi sʌmdeɪ jə tu kən kənvɪns tuɑn ə ðə tʃɹuθ. hɛlp mi faɪn ə weɪ tə fɪks ðɪs wɪθaʊt kɑzɪŋ ði ɛmpaɪɝ tə kəlæps."

"Go with the Aes Sedai," Mat said. "I'll give you your own horses, so you don't have to rely on them. Learn to channel. That'll be more use than dying. Maybe someday you two can convince Tuon of the truth. Help me find a way to fix this without causing the Empire to collapse."

ðə tu wɪmən lʊk tə hɪm, mɔɹ fɝm ən kɑnfəɾənt, sʌɾənli. "jɛs, haɪnəs," bɛθəmən sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz ə ɡʊd pɝpəs fəɹ əs tə hæv. θæŋk ju, haɪnəs."

The two women looked to him, more firm and confident, suddenly. "Yes, Highness," Bethamin said. "It is a good purpose for us to have. Thank you, Highness."

sɛɾə æktʃəli  ɡɑt tɪɹz ɪn əɹ aɪz! wʌd dɪd ðeɪ θɪŋk i hæd dʒʌs pɹɑməs ðɛm? mæt ɹitʃɹiɾəd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd ɡɛɾ ɛni mɔɹ ɑɾ aɪdiəz ɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz. fleɪmɪŋ wɪmən. stɪl, hi kəd nɑt hɛlp filɪŋ sɑɹi fəɹ ðɛm. lɝnɪŋ ðət ðeɪ kəd tʃænəl, wɝiɪŋ ðeɪ maɪt bi ə deɪnʒɝ tə ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Seta actually got tears in her eyes! Light, what did they think he had just promised them? Mat retreated before they could get any more odd ideas in their heads. Flaming women. Still, he could not help feeling sorry for them. Learning that they could channel, worrying they might be a danger to everyone around them.

ðæts baʊ ɹænd fɛlt, mæt θɔt. pʊɹ ful. əz ɔlweɪz, ðə kʌlɝz swɝld wən i θɔɾ ə ɹænd. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə də ɪt tu ɔfən, ən bɪfɔɹ i kəd bænɪʃ ðoʊz kʌlɝz, hi kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə ɹænd ʃeɪvɪŋ ɪn ə faɪn, ɡɪldɪd mɪɹɝ hæŋɪŋ ɪn ə bjuɾəfəl beɪðɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ.

That's bow Rand felt, Mat thought. Poor fool. As always, the colors swirled when he thought of Rand. He tried not to do it too often, and before he could banish those colors, he caught a glimpse of Rand shaving in a fine, gilded mirror hanging in a beautiful bathing chamber.

mæt ɡeɪv səm ɔɹɾɝz tə ɡɛt ðə sʌldəm hɔɹsəz, ðən i wɔkt oʊvɝ təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. tɑm hæɾ ɝaɪvd ən i stʃɹoʊld oʊvɝ. "laɪt, mæt," hi sɛd. "ju lʊk laɪk jə tæŋɡəld wɪð ə bɹaɪɹstɪtʃ pætʃ ən keɪm aʊt sɔɹ.

Mat gave some orders to get the sul'dam horses, then he walked over toward the Aes Sedai. Thom had arrived and he strolled over. "Light, Mat," he said. "You look like you tangled with a briarstitch patch and came out sore.

mæt ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɪz hɛɹ, wɪtʃ wɑz pɹɑbli ə ɹil saɪt. "aɪ lɪv ðə naɪt, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ livɪŋ. aɪv hæf ə maɪn tə dæns ə dʒɪɡ ət ðæt." 'θɔɹn snɔɹɾɪd. "dɪd jə noʊ ðoʊz tu wɝ gɑnə bi hɪɹ?"

Mat raised a hand to his hair, which was probably a real sight. "I lived the night, and the Aes Sedai are leaving. I've half a mind to dance a jig at that." 'Thorn snorted. "Did you know those two were going to be here?"

"ðə sʌldəm? aɪ fɪɡjɝd."

"The sul'dam? I figured."

"noʊ, ðoʊz tu." hi pɔɪntəd.

"No, those two." He pointed.

mæt tɝnd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əz i faʊn laɪlwɪn ən beɪl doʊmən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ pəzɛʃənz wɝ ɹoʊld ʌp ɑn ðə bæks ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. laɪlwɪn - ðən noʊn əz ɛdʒiənɪn - hæd wʌns bɪn ə sintʃæn noʊbəlwʊmən, bʌt tuɑn hæd stʃɹɪpt əɹ neɪm əweɪ. ʃi wɔɹ ə dʒɹɛs wɪð dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ə mjuɾɪd ɡɹeɪ. hɝ ʃɔɹt dɑɹk hɛɹ hæd ɡɹoʊn aʊt, ən hʌŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ɪɹz.

Mat turned, frowning as he found Leilwin and Bayle Domon riding Their possessions were rolled up on the backs of their horses. Leilwin - then known as Egeanin - had once been a Seanchan noblewoman, but Tuon had stripped her name away. She wore a dress with divided skirts of muted gray. Her short dark hair had grown out, and hung over her ears.

ʃi klaɪm fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ən stɔkt ɪn mæts dɝɛkʃən.

She climbed from her saddle and stalked in Mat's direction.

"bɝn mi," mæt sɛd tə θɔɹn, "ɪf aɪ kən bi ɹɪɾ ə hɝ, tu, əl ɔlmoʊst stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ ðət laɪf əz tɝn fɛɹ ɑn mi."

"Burn me," Mat said to Thorn, "if I can be rid of her, too, I'll almost start thinking that life has turned fair on me."

doʊmən fɑloʊɾ əɹ əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt. hi wɑz əɹ sɔɪhɪn. əɹ . . . kəɾ i stɪl bi sɔɪhɪn, naʊ ðət ʃi hæd noʊ taɪɾəl? wɛl, iðɝ weɪ, hi wɑz əɹ hʌzbənd. ði ɪliɑnɝ wɑz θɪk ʌv ɡɝθ, ən stʃɹɔŋ.

Domon followed her as they approached. He was her so'jhin. Or . . . could he still be so'jhin, now that she had no title? Well, either way, he was her husband. The Illianer was thick of girth, and strong.

hi wɑz nɑt tu bæɾ ə fɛloʊ, ɪksɛpt wən i wɑz ɝaʊn laɪlwɪn. wɪtʃ wɑz ɔlweɪz.

He was not too bad a fellow, except when he was around Leilwin. Which was always.

"kɔθən," ʃi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm.

"Cauthon," she said, stepping up to him.

"Leilwin," he replied. "You're leaving?"

"jɛs."

"Yes."

mæt smaɪld. hi ɹɪli wɑz gɑnə də ðət dæns!

Mat smiled. He really was going to do that dance!

"aɪ ɔlweɪz ɪntɛndəd tə meɪk maɪ weɪ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ," ʃi kəntɪnjud. "aɪ sɛt maɪ maɪn ðəɹ ɑn ðə deɪ aɪ lɛft ɛbu dɑɹ. ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ livɪŋ, əl ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm. ə ʃɪp ɪz ɔlweɪz waɪz tə dʒɔɪn ə kɑnvɔɪ, wən ðə ɹaɪɾ ɑpɝtunəɾi ɪz pɹizɛntəd."

"I always intended to make my way to the White Tower," she continued. "I set my mind there on the day I left Ebou Dar. If the Aes Sedai are leaving, I will go with them. A ship is always wise to join a convoy, when the right opportunity is presented."

"tu bæd tə si jə ɡoʊ," mæt laɪd, tɪpɪŋ ɪz hæt tə hɝ. laɪlwɪn wɑz əz tʌf əz ə hʌnʒɹəd-jɪɹ oʊk stʌk wɪð bɪts ʌv æks lɛft oʊvɝ fɹəm ðə mɛn fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ tə tʃɑp ɪt daʊn. ɪf əɹ hɔɹs θɹu ə ʃu ɑn ðə ɹoʊd tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ʃi wəd laɪkli slɪŋ ði ænəməl oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən kæɹi ɪt ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ.

"Too bad to see you go," Mat lied, tipping his hat to her. Leilwin was as tough as a hundred-year oak stuck with bits of axe left over from the men foolish enough to try to chop it down. If her horse threw a shoe on the road to Tar Valon, she would likely sling the animal over her shoulder and carry it the rest of the way.

bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk mæt, fəɹ ɔl i hæd dʌn tə seɪv əɹ skɪn. meɪbi ɪt wɑz kəz i hæd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ, əɹ meɪbi kəz ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹst æk laɪk ɪz lʌvɝ. wɛl, hi hæd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪd ðət pɑɹɾ iðɝ. ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk hoʊldɪŋ ə sɔɹd baɪ ðə bleɪɾ ən pɹitɛndɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt stɪŋ.

But she did not like Mat, for all he had done to save her skin. Maybe it was because he had not let her take charge, or maybe because she had been forced act like his lover. Well, he had not enjoyed that part either. It had been like holding a sword by the blade and pretending that it did not sting.

ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn fʌn tə wɑtʃ əɹ skwɝm.

Though it had been fun to watch her squirm.

"bi wɛl, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," laɪlwɪn sɛd. "aɪ doʊn ɛnvi ðə pleɪs juv pʊt jɝsɛlf ɪn. ɪn səm weɪz, aɪ θɪŋk ðə wɪnz ðət kæɹi jə meɪ æktu-ælaɪ bi ɹʌfɝ ðən ðə wʌnz wɪtʃ əv bəfeɪd mi, ɹisənli." ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɪm, ðən tɝn tə ɡoʊ.

"Be well, Matrim Cauthon," Leilwin said. "I don't envy the place you've put yourself in. In some ways, I think the winds that carry you may actu-ally be rougher than the ones which have buffeted me, recently." She nodded to him, then turned to go.

doʊmən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn mæts ɑɹm. "ju dɪd də əz jə sɛd. baɪ maɪ eɪdʒd ɡɹændmʌðɝ! jə ɡeɪv ə bʌmpi ɹaɪɾ ʌv ɪt, bʌt jə dɪd də əz jə sɛd. maɪ θæŋks."

Domon reached over, laying a hand on Mat's arm. "You did do as you said. By my aged grandmother! You gave a bumpy ride of it, but you did do as you said. My thanks."

ðə tu ʌv əm muvd ɔf. mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, weɪvɪŋ tə tɑm ən stʃɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "tɛslɪn," mæt sɛd. "idɛzinə. dʒoʊlin. ɔl ' wɛl?"

The two of them moved off. Mat shook his head, waving to Thom and strolling over to the Aes Sedai. "Teslyn," Mat said. "Edesina. Joline. All ' well?"

"ɪɾ ɪz," dʒoʊlin sɛd.

"It is," Joline said.

"ɡʊd, ɡʊd," mæt sɛd. "ju hæv səfɪʃən pæk ænəməlz?"

"Good, good," Mat said. "You have sufficient pack animals?"

"ðeɪ wɪl du, mæstɝ kɔθən," dʒoʊlin sɛd. ðɛn, kʌvɝɪŋ ə wɪns ʃi æɾəd, "θæŋk jə fəɹ ɡɪvɪŋ əm tə ʌs."

"They will do, Master Cauthon," Joline said. Then, covering a wince she added, "Thank you for giving them to us."

mæt smaɪl bɹɔdli. maɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əmjuzɪŋ tə hɪɹ əɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əkɝ ɹɪspɛkfəl! ʃi hæɾ ɑbviəsli ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪleɪn tə wɛlkəm əɹ ən ði ʌðɝz wɪð oʊpən ɑɹmz, nɑt tɝn əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə pæləs wɪθaʊɾ ən ɑɾiəns.

Mat smiled broadly. My, but it was amusing to hear her trying to acr respectful! She had obviously expected Elayne to welcome her and the others with open arms, not turn them away from the palace without an audience.

dʒoʊlin aɪd mæt, lʌʃ lɪps pɹɛs təɡɛðɝ. "aɪ wəd laɪk tə hæv teɪm ju, kɔθən," ʃi sɛd.

Joline eyed Mat, lush lips pressed together. "I would liked to have tamed you, Cauthon," she said.

"aɪv stɪl hæf ə maɪn tə ɹɪtɝn sʌmdeɪ ən si ðə dʒɑb dʌn pɹɑpɝli."

"I've still half a mind to return someday and see the job done properly."

"aɪl weɪt bɹɛθləsli fəɹ ðæt, ðɛn," hi sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ðə klɔθ-ɹæpt pækədʒ fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. hi hændəɾ ɪɾ ʌp tə hɝ.

"I'll wait breathlessly for that, then," he said, taking the cloth-wrapped package from under his arm. He handed it up to her.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" ʃi æskt, nɑt ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪt.

"What is this?" she asked, not reaching for it.

mæt ʃʊk ðə bʌndəl. "pɑɹɾɪŋ ɡɪft," hi sɛd. "wɛɹ aɪ kʌm fɹʌm, jə nɛvɝ lɛɾ ə tʃɹævəlɝ dɪpɑɹt wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹoʊd. ɪt wəd bi ɹud."

Mat shook the bundle. "Parting gift," he said. "Where I come from, you never let a traveler depart without giving her something for the road. It would be rude."

ɹɪlʌktənli, ʃi æksɛptɪɾ ɪɾ ən pikt ɪnsaɪd. ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðəɾ ɪt kənteɪn ə kəlɛkʃən ʌv əbaʊɾ ə dʌzən paʊɾɝd switbənz. "θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

Reluctantly, she accepted it and peeked inside. She was obviously surprised to find that it contained a collection of about a dozen powdered sweetbuns. "Thank you," she said, frowning.

"aɪm sɛndɪŋ soʊlʒɝz wɪð ju," mæt sɛd. "ðeɪl bɹɪŋ maɪ hɔɹsəz bæk wʌns jə ɝaɪv ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"I'm sending soldiers with you," Mat said. "They'll bring my horses back once you arrive in Tar Valon."

dʒoʊlin oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əz ɪf tə kəmpleɪn, bʌt ðən kloʊzd ɪt. wʌɾ ɑɹɡjəmən kəd ʃi meɪk?

Joline opened her mouth as if to complain, but then closed it. What argument could she make?

"ðæt wɪl bi æksɛptəbəl, kɔθən," tɛslɪn sɛd, muvɪŋ əɹ blæk ɡɛldɪŋ kloʊsɝ.

"That will be acceptable, Cauthon," Teslyn said, moving her black gelding closer.

"aɪl ɡɪv əm ɔɹɾɝz tə də əz jə seɪ," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə hɝ. "soʊ jəl əv pipəl tə kəmæn əbaʊɾ ən meɪk sɛɾ ʌp jəɹ tɛns. bʌt ðɛɹz ə kəndɪʃən ətætʃt."

"I'll give them orders to do as you say," Mat said, turning to her. "So you'll have people to command about and make set up your tents. But there's a condition attached."

tɛslɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Teslyn raised an eyebrow.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə tɛl ði æmɪɝlɪn sʌmθɪŋ," hi sɛd. "ɪf ɪts ɛɡwin, ðɪs ʃəd bi izi. bʌɾ ivən ɪf ɪɾ ɪzənt, jə tɛl hɝ. ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz sʌmθɪŋ ə maɪn, ən ɪts nɪɹli taɪm ðəɾ aɪ ɹikleɪmd ɪt.

"I want you to tell the Amyrlin something," he said. "If it's Egwene, this should be easy. But even if it isn't, you tell her. The White Tower has something of mine, and it's nearly time that I reclaimed it.

aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə, bʌt wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt nɛvɝ simz tə mæɾɝ ə wɪskɝ, ðiz deɪz. soʊ əl bi kʌmɪŋ, ən aɪ doʊn min tə bi blʌɾi tɝn əweɪ. " hi smaɪld. "jus ðəɾ ɪɡzæk læŋɡwədʒ."

I don't want to, but what I want never seems to matter a whisker, these days. So I'll be coming, and I don't mean to be bloody turned away. " He smiled. "Use that exact language."

tɛslɪn, tə hɝ kɹɛɾət, tʃʌkəl sɔfli. "aɪl si ɪt dʌn, ðoʊ aɪ daʊt ɹumɝz ɑɹ tʃɹu. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑɾ əv ɡɪvən ʌp ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

Testlyn, to her credit, chuckled softly. "I'll see it done, though I doubt rumors are true. Elaida would not have given up the Amyrlin Seat."

"ju maɪt bi sɝpɹaɪzd." mæt ʃʊɹli hæd bɪn, wən i hæd dɪskʌvɝd wɪmən kɔlɪŋ ɛɡwin æmɪɝlɪn. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt hæd hæpn ʌp ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌɾ i hæɾ ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd ɹæpt pʊɹ ɛɡwin ʌp ɪn ðɛɹ skimz soʊ saʊnli ðət ʃi wəd nɛvɝ ɪskeɪp. hi hæd hæf ə maɪn tə ɹaɪɾ ʌp ðəɹ hɪmsɛlf ən si ɪf i kəd ɡɛɾ əɹ aʊt. bʌɾ i hæɾ ʌðɝ tæsks. ɛɡwin wəɾ əv tə si tə hɝsɛlf fəɹ naʊ. ʃi wɑz ə keɪpəbəl ɡɝl; ʃi kəd pɹɑbli hændəl ɪt wɪθaʊɾ ɪm fəɹ ə waɪl.

"You might be surprised." Mat surely had been, when he had discovered women calling Egwene Amyrlin. He did not know what had hapned up at the White Tower, but he had a sinking feeling that the Aes Sedai had wrapped poor Egwene up in their schemes so soundly that she would never escape. He had half a mind to ride up there himself and see if he could get her out. But he had other tasks. Egwene would have to see to herself for now. She was a capable girl; she could probably handle it without him for a while.

θɔɹn stʊd tə hɪz saɪd, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəl. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ ðət mæt hæd bloʊn ðə hɔɹn  - ət list, mæt hæd nɛvɝ toʊl hɪm. hi tʃɹaɪd tə fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ. bʌt θɔɹn hæd pɹɑbli ɡɛst.

Thorn stood to his side, looking thoughtful. He did not know for sure that Mat had blown the Horn  - at least, Mat had never told him. He tried to forget about the bloody thing. But Thorn had probably guessed.

"wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz jə ʃəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ," mæt sɛd. "wɛɹz sɛɾəl?"

"Well, I suppose you should be going," Mat said. "Where's Setalle?"

"ʃil bi steɪɪŋ hɪɹ," tɛslɪn sɛd. "ʃi sɛd ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə kip jə fɹəm meɪkɪŋ tu mɛni mɪsstɛps." ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ən dʒoʊlin ən idɛzinə nɑɾəd sɑɡæʃəsli. ðeɪ ɔl əsum ðət sɛɾəl wɑz ə fɔɹmɝ ɹʌnəweɪ sɝvən fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ, pɝhæps hævɪŋ flɛɾ əz ə ɡɝl kəz ʌv ə mɪsdid.

"She'll be staying here," Teslyn said. "She said that she wanted to keep you from making too many missteps." She raised an eyebrow, and Joline and Edesina nodded sagaciously. They all assumed that Setalle was a former runaway servant from the White Tower, perhaps having fled as a girl because of a misdeed.

wɛl, ðət mɛn i wʊdn bi ɹɪɾ ə ði ɪntaɪɝ ɡɹup. stɪl, ɪf i hæd tə pɪk wʌn tə steɪ, ɪt wəd bi mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən. ʃi wəd pɹɑbli bi wɑntɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə miɾ ʌp wɪð əɹ hʌzbən ən fæmli, hu hæd flɛɾ ɛbu dɑɹ baɪ ʃɪp.

Well, that meant he wouldn't be rid of the entire group. Still, if he had to pick one to stay, it would be Mistress Anan. She would probably be wanting to find a way to meet up with her husband and family, who had fled Ebou Dar by ship.

dʒulɪn wɔkt ʌp, liɾɪŋ θɛɹə. hæd ðət fɹaɪɾənd wɪsp ʌv ə wʊmən ɹɪli bɪn ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ ə tæɹɑbən? mæt hæd sin maɪs ðət wɝ lɛs tɪmɪd. mæts soʊlʒɝz bɹɔɾ aʊt hɔɹsəz fəɹ ðə tu ʌv ðɛm. ɔl ɪn ɔl, ðɪs ɛkspədɪʃən wɑz kɔstɪŋ ɪm səm fɔɹɾi ænəməlz ən ə faɪl ə soʊlʒɝz. bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi wɝθ ɪt. bɪsaɪdz, hi ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɪtʃɹiv boʊθ mɛn ən hɔɹsəz - əlɔŋ wɪð ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt wʌt wɑz ɹɪli hæpənɪŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn.

Juilin walked up, leading Thera. Had that frightened wisp of a woman really been the Panarch of Tarabon? Mat had seen mice that were less timid. Mat's soldiers brought out horses for the two of them. All in all, this expedition was costing him some forty animals and a file of soldiers. But it would be worth it. Besides, he intended to retrieve both men and horses - along with information about what was really happening in Tar Valon.

hi nɑɾəd tə veɪnɪn. ðə θɪk-weɪstɪd hɔɹs θif hæd nɑt bɪn tu plizd wən mæt hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪm tə ɡoʊ əlɔŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ɡæðɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. mæt hæd fɪɡjɝɾ i wəd bi ɛkstæɾɪk, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ hi dɑɾɪd ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɛl, hi wəd bi ivən lɛs hæpi wən i faʊn dʒulɪn wɑz əlɔŋ; veɪnɪn tɛndəd tə stɛp laɪtli ɝaʊn ðə θif-kætʃɝ.

He nodded to Vanin. The thick-waisted horse thief had not been too pleased when Mat had ordered him to go along to Tar Valon and gather information. Mat had figured he would be ecstatic, considering how he doted on the Aes Sedai. Well, he would be even less happy when he found Juilin was along; Vanin tended to step lightly around the thief-catcher.

veɪnɪn maʊntəɾ ə beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ. əz fɑɹ əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nu, hi wɑz ə sinjɝ ɹɛdɑɹm ən wʌn ə mæts fil skaʊts, bʌt noʊbɑdi tə bi səspɪʃəs ʌv. wi dɪd nɑt lʊk vɛɹi θɹɛɾənɪŋ, ɪksɛp meɪbi əz ə deɪnʒɝ tə ə boʊl ə bɔɪl pəteɪɾoʊz. ðət maɪt bi waɪ hi wɑz soʊ ɡʊɾ ət wʌɾ i dɪd. mæt dɪd nɑt niɾ ɛni hɔɹsəz stoʊlən, bʌt veɪnɪnz tæləns kəd bi əplaɪd tə ʌðɝ tæsks.

Vanin mounted a bay gelding. As far as the Aes Sedai knew, he was a senior Redarm and one of Mat's field scouts, but nobody to be suspicious of. We did not look very threatening, except maybe as a danger to a bowl of boiled potatoes. That might be why he was so good at what he did. Mat did not need any horses stolen, but Vanin's talents could be applied to other tasks.

"wɛl," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, "aɪ woʊn kip jə fɝðɝ, ðɛn." hi stɛp bæk, əvɔɪɾɪŋ lʊkɪŋ ət dʒoʊlin - hu hæɾ ə pɹɛɾətɔɹi kæs tə hɝ aɪz ðət ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ɔl tu mʌtʃ ə taɪlɪn. tɛslɪn weɪvd ænd, kjʊɹiəsli, idɛzinə nɑɾəd tə hɪm ɪn ɹɪspɛkt. dʒulɪn hæɾ ə weɪv fəɹ ɪm ən θɔɹn, ən mæt ɡɑɾ ə nɑd fɹəm laɪlwɪn. ðə wʊmən tʃud ɹɑks fəɹ bɹɛkfəst ən neɪlz fəɹ sʌpɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz fɛɹ. meɪbi hi kəd tɔk tə tuɑn, ɡɛɾ əɹ ɹiɪnsteɪɾɪd əɹ sʌmθɪŋ.

"Well," Mat said, turning back to the Aes Sedai, "I won't keep you further, then." He stepped back, avoiding looking at Joline - who had a predatory cast to her eyes that reminded him all too much of Tylin. Teslyn waved and, curiously, Edesina nodded to him in respect. Juilin had a wave for him and Thorn, and Mat got a nod from Leilwin. The woman chewed rocks for breakfast and nails for supper, but she was fair. Maybe he could talk to Tuon, get her reinstated or something.

doʊn bi ə ful, hi θɔt, ɡɪvɪŋ ə weɪv tə beɪl doʊmən. fɝs jəl nid tə kənvɪns tuɑn nɑt tə meɪk jə dækoʊvæl. hi wɑz hæf kənvɪnst ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə si hɪm əz əɹ sɝvənt, hʌzbən əɹ nɑt.

Don't be a fool, he thought, giving a wave to Bayle Domon. First you'll need to convince Tuon not to make you da'covale. He was half convinced she intended to see him as her servant, husband or not.

θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðət meɪɾ ɪm swɛɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɑlɝ.

Thinking about that made him sweat around the collar.

bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ðeɪ wɝ meɪkɪŋ dʌst əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd. θɔɹn stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd mæt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz. "switbənz?"

Before long, they were making dust along the road. Thorn stepped up beside Mat, watching the riders. "Sweetbuns?"

"tʃɹədɪʃən əmʌŋ əs tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk."

"Tradition among us Two Rivers folk."

"nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðət tʃɹədɪʃən."

"Never heard of that tradition."

"ɪts vɛɹi əbskjʊɹ."

"It's very obscure."

"ɑ, aɪ si. ən wʌd jə də tə ðoʊz bʌnz?"

"Ah, I see. And what did you do to those buns?"

"spɹɪŋklwɝt," mæt sɛd. "ɪɾəl tɝn əɹ maʊθ blu fəɹ ə wik, meɪbi tu. ən ʃi woʊnt ʃɛɹ ðə switbənz wɪð ɛniwʌn, ɪksɛp meɪbi hɝ wɔɹɾɝz. dʒoʊlin ɪz ədɪktəd tə ðə θɪŋz. ʃi mʌst əv iɾən sɛvən əɹ eɪt bæɡz' wɝθ sɪns wi ɡɑt tə keɪɛmlɪn."

"Sprinklewort," Mat said. "It'll turn her mouth blue for a week, maybe two. And she won't share the sweetbuns with anyone, except maybe her Warders. Joline is addicted to the things. She must have eaten seven or eight bags' worth since we got to Caemlyn."

"naɪs," θɔɹn sɛd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃ. "tʃaɪldɪʃ, ðoʊ."

"Nice," Thorn said, knuckling his mustache. "Childish, though."

"aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt bæk tə maɪ beɪsɪk ɹuts," mæt sɛd. "ju noʊ, ɹikæptʃɝ səm ə maɪ lɔs juθ."

"I'm trying to get back to my basic roots," Mat said. "You know, recapture some of my lost youth."

"jɔɹ bɛɹli twɛnti wɪntɝz oʊld!"

"You're barely twenty winters old!"

"ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ aɪ dɪɾ ə lɑɾ ə lɪvɪŋ wən aɪ wɑz jʌŋɡɝ. kʌm ɑn. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɪz steɪɪŋ, ən ðət ɡɪvz mi ən aɪdiə."

"Sure, but I did a lot of living when I was younger. Come on. Mistress Anan is staying, and that gives me an idea."

"ju niɾ ə ʃeɪv, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən." mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz əz ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɪm.

"You need a shave, Matrim Cauthon." Mistress Anan folded her arms as she regarded him.

hi ɹitʃt ʌp, tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz feɪs. ləpɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz dʌn ðæt, itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ. ðə mæn ɡɑɾ əz sʌlki əz ə dɔɡ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn wən mæt dɪd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm də sətʃ θɪŋz, ðoʊ leɪtli mæt hæd bɪn ɡɹoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz bɪɹd tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs. ɪt stɪl ɪtʃt laɪk ə wik-oʊl skæb.

He reached up, touching his face. Lopin had always done that, each morning. The man got as sulky as a dog in the rain when Mat did not let him do such things, though lately Mat had been growing out his beard to avoid notice. It still itched like a week-old scab.

hi hæd faʊn sɛɾəl ət ðə səplaɪ tɛns, oʊvɝsiɪŋ ðə mɪddeɪ mil-soʊlʒɝz fɹəm ðə bæn hʌŋkɝd daʊn, tʃɑpɪŋ vɛdʒtəbəlz ən stuɪŋ binz wɪð ðə fɝɾɪv ɪkspɹɛʃən ə mɛn u hæd bɪn ɡɪvən fɝm ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. sɛɾəl wɑz nɑt niɾəd hɪɹ; ðə bænz kʊks hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn eɪbəl tə pɹipɛɹ milz wɪθaʊt hɝ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ə wʊmən laɪk bɛɾɝ ðən faɪndɪŋ mɛn u wɝ ɹɪlæksɪŋ, ðən ɡɪvɪŋ əm ɔɹɾɝz. bɪsaɪdz, sɛɾəl wɑz ə fɔɹmɝ ɪnkipɝ ən - ɹɪmɑɹkəbli - ə fɔɹmɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. mæt ɔfən faʊn əɹ supɝvaɪzɪŋ θɪŋz ðət dɪd nɑt nid supɝvaɪzɪŋ.

He had found Setalle at the supply tents, overseeing the midday meal-Soldiers from the Band hunkered down, chopping vegetables and stewing beans with the furtive expression of men who had been given firm instructions. Setalle was not needed here; the Band's cooks had always been able to prepare meals without her. But there was nothing a woman liked better than finding men who were relaxing, then giving them orders. Besides, Setalle was a former innkeeper and - remarkably - a former Aes Sedai. Mat often found her supervising things that did not need supervising.

nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi wɪʃt tuɑn wɝ stɪl tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð hɪm. sɛɾəl hæd juʒəwəli teɪkən tuɑnz saɪd, bʌt steɪɪŋ wɪð ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz hæɾ ɔfən kɛpt əɹ bɪzi. nʌθɪŋ wɑz mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ðə sænəɾi ʌv mɛn ðən ə wʊmən wɪð tu mʌtʃ taɪm ɑn əɹ hænz.

Not for the first time, he wished Tuon were still traveling with him. Setalle had usually taken Tuon's side, but staying with the Daughter of the Nine Moons had often kept her busy. Nothing was more dangerous for the sanity of men than a woman with too much time on her hands.

sɛɾəl stɪl wɔɹ kloʊðɪŋ ə ði ɛbu dɑɹi staɪl, wɪtʃ mæt faʊn plɛzənt, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə plʌnʒɪŋ nɛklaɪn. ðət kaɪndə aʊtfɪt wɝk pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɛl ɑn ə wʊmən əz bʌksəm əz sɛɾəl. nɑt ðəɾ i noʊɾəst. ʃi hæd ɡoʊldən hups ɪn əɹ ɪɹz, ə steɪtli dɪminɝ ən ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ. ðə dʒuəld wɛɾɪŋ naɪf wɔɹn ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk sim sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə wɔɹnɪŋ, ðə weɪ ɪt nɛsəld ɪn əɹ klivədʒ. nɑt ðət mæt noʊɾəst ðæt, iðɝ.

Setalle still wore clothing of the Ebou Dari style, which Mat found pleasant, considering the plunging neckline. That kind of outfit worked particularly well on a woman as buxom as Setalle. Not that he noticed. She had golden hoops in her ears, a stately demeanor and gray in her hair. The jeweled wedding knife worn around her neck seemed something of a warning, the way it nestled in her cleavage. Not that Mat noticed that, either.

"aɪv bɪn ɡɹoʊɪŋ ðə bɪɹɾ ɪntɛnʃənəli," mæt sɛd tə hɝ steɪtmənt. "aɪ wɑnə - "

"I've been growing the beard intentionally," Mat said to her statement. "I want to - "

"jɔɹ koʊɾ ɪz dɝɾi," ʃi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə soʊlʒɝ u bɹɔɾ əɹ səm ʌnjənz i hæd pild.

"Your coat is dirty," she said, nodding to a soldier who brought her some onions he had peeled.

hi ʃipɪʃli pɔɹɾ əm ɪndə ə pɑt, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət mæt. "æn jəɹ hɛɹ ə mɛs. jə lʊk laɪk juv bɪn ɪn ə bɹɔl, ən ɪts nɑt jɛt nun."

He sheepishly poured them into a pot, not looking at Mat. "And your hair a mess. You look like you've been in a brawl, and it's not yet noon."

"aɪm faɪn," mæt sɛd. "aɪl klin ʌp leɪɾɝ. jə dɪdnt ɡoʊ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I'm fine," Mat said. "I'll clean up later. You didn't go with the Aes Sedai."

"itʃ stɛp təwɔɹd tɑɹ vəlɑn wəd teɪk mi fɑɹðɝ fɹəm wɛɹ aɪ nid tə bi. aɪ nid tə sɛnd wɝd tə maɪ hʌzbənd. wən wi pɑɹɾəd, aɪ dɪdn səspɛk ðəɾ aɪɾ ɛn ʌp ɪn ændɝ ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz."

"Each step toward Tar Valon would take me farther from where I need to be. I need to send word to my husband. When we parted, I didn't suspect that I'd end up in Andor of all places."

"aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ aɪ maɪt bi ɡɛɾɪŋ æksɛs tə sʌmwʌn u kən meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz hɪɹ sun," mæt sɛd.

"I'm thinking I might be getting access to someone who can make gateways here soon," Mat said.

"æn aɪ . . ." hi fɹaʊn əz ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz əpɹoʊtʃt, kæɹiɪŋ ə fju ʌndɝsaɪz kweɪl ðeɪd hʌntəd. ðə soʊlʒɝz lʊkt əʃeɪmd ə ðə tɛɹəbəl kætʃ.

"And I . . ." He frowned as another group of soldiers approached, carrying a few undersized quail they'd hunted. The soldiers looked ashamed of the terrible catch.

sɛɾəl ɔɹɾɝd əm tə plʌk ðə bɝdz wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns təwɔɹd mæt. laɪt, hi niɾəd tə ɡɛɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz kæmp. θɪŋz wəd nɑt bi nɔɹməl hɪɹ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɔn.

Setalle ordered them to pluck the birds without so much as a glance toward Mat. Light, he needed to get her out of his camp. Things would not be normal here until they were all gone.

"doʊn lʊk ət mi laɪk ðæt, lɔɹd mæt," sɛɾəl sɛd. "nɔɹæm wɛn ɪndə ðə sɪɾi tə si wʌt kaɪndə pɹəvɪʒənz i kəd faɪnd. aɪv noʊɾəd ðət wɪθaʊt ðə kʊk hɪmsɛlf hɪɹ tə pɹɑd ðə mɛn, milz doʊnt ɡɛt dʌn əɾ ɛni ɹizənəbəl spid. nɑɾ ɔl ʌv əs laɪk tə teɪk lʌntʃ wən ðə sʌn ɪz sɛɾɪŋ." aɪ dɪdn seɪ ə θɪŋ," mæt sɛd, kipɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs ivən. hi nɑɾəd tə ðə saɪd. "kæn wi tɔk fəɹ ə moʊmənt?"

"Don't look at me like that, Lord Mat," Setalle said. "Noram went into the city to see what kind of provisions he could find. I've noted that without the cook himself here to prod the men, meals don't get done at any reasonable speed. Not all of us like to take lunch when the sun is setting." I didn't say a thing," Mat said, keeping his voice even. He nodded to the side. "Can we talk for a moment?"

sɛɾəl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd ən stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝz wɪð hɪm. "wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɹɪli?" ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "ju lʊk laɪk jə slɛpt ʌndɝ ə heɪ paɪl."

Setalle hesitated, then nodded and stepped away from the others with him. "What's going on really?" she said softly. "You look like you slept under a hay pile."

"aɪ slɛpt ʌndɝ ə wæɡən, æktʃəli . ən maɪ tɛns steɪnd wɪð blʌd nɑt ɹɪli lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə ɡoʊɪŋ ðəɹ tə tʃeɪnʒ kloʊðɪŋ ɹaɪt naʊ"

"I slept under a wagon, actually. And my tent's stained with blood Not really looking forward to going there to change clothing right now"

hɝ ɡeɪz sɔfənd. "aɪ ʌndɝstæn jəɹ lɔs. bʌt ðæts noʊ ɪkskjus tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊn lʊkɪŋ laɪk juv bɪn lɪvɪŋ ɪn ən æliweɪ. jəl nid tə haɪɝ ənʌðɝ sɝvɪŋ mæn."

Her gaze softened. "I understand your loss. But that's no excuse to go around looking like you've been living in an alleyway. You'll need to hire another serving man."

mæt skaʊld. "aɪ nɛvɝ niɾəd wʌn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. aɪ kən teɪk kɛɹ ə maɪsɛlf. lʊk, aɪ hæv ə feɪvɝ tə æsk ə ju. aɪ wɑn jə tə wɑtʃ æftɝ oʊlvɝ fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl."

Mat scowled. "I never needed one in the first place. I can take care of myself. Look, I have a favor to ask of you. I want you to watch after Olver for a little while."

"fɔɹ wʌt pɝpəs?"

"For what purpose?"

"ðæt θɪŋ maɪt kʌm bæk," mæt sɛd. "æn ɪt kəd tʃɹaɪ tə hɝt hɪm. bɪsaɪdz, aɪm gɑnə bi livɪŋ wɪð θɔɹn ʃɔɹtli. aɪ maɪt bi bæk aɪ ʃəd bi bæk. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ doʊnt, aɪ . . . wɛl, aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ i nɑt bi lɛft əloʊn."

"That thing might come back," Mat said. "And it could try to hurt him. Besides, I'm going to be leaving with Thorn shortly. I might be back I should be back. But if I don't, I . . . Well, I would rather he not be left alone."

ʃi stʌɾid hɪm. "hi wəd nɑt bi əloʊn. ðə mɛn ɪn kæmp sim tə hæv ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə fɑndnəs fəɹ ðə tʃaɪld."

She studied him. "He would not be alone. The men in camp seem to have a great deal of fondness for the child."

"ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn laɪk ðə θɪŋz ðəɹ titʃɪŋ hɪm. ðə bɔɪ nidz bɛɾɝ ɪɡzæmpəlz ðən ðət lɑt."

"Sure, but I don't like the things they're teaching him. The boy needs better examples than that lot."

ʃi simd əmjuz baɪ ðət fəɹ səm ɹizən. "aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ ðə tʃaɪld ɪn lɛɾɝz. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kən wɑtʃ æftɝ ɪm fəɹ ə taɪm, ɪf nid bi."

She seemed amused by that for some reason. "I've already begun instructing the child in letters. I suppose I can watch after him for a time, if need be."

"ɡɹeɪt. wʌndɝfəl." mæt lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɪliv saɪ. wɪmən wɝ ɔlweɪz hæpi fəɹ ə tʃæns tə ɛdʒəkeɪɾ ə bɔɪ wən i wɑz jʌŋ; mæt θɔt ðeɪ əsum ðeɪ kəɾ ɛdʒəkeɪɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə mæn ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf. "aɪl ɡɪv jə səm mʌni. jə kən ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ən faɪn ən ɪn."

"Great. Wonderful." Mat let out a relieved sigh. Women were always happy for a chance to educate a boy when he was young; Mat thought they assumed they could educate him out of becoming a man if they tried hard enough. "I'll give you some money. You can go into the city and find an inn."

"aɪv bɪn ɪndə ðə sɪɾi," sɛɾəl sɛd. "ɛvɹi ɪn ɪn ðə pleɪs simz pæk tə ðə wɔlz ɔlɹɛɾi."

"I've been into the city," Setalle said. "Every inn in the place seems packed to the walls already."

"aɪl faɪn ə pleɪs fəɹ ju," mæt pɹɑməst. "dʒʌs kip oʊlvɝ seɪf. wən ðə taɪm kʌmz, ən aɪ hæv sʌmwʌn tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz, əl əv əm sɛn jə tə ɪljən soʊ jə kən faɪn jəɹ hʌzbənd."

"I'll find a place for you," Mat promised. "Just keep Olver safe. When the time comes, and I have someone to make gateways, I'll have them send you to Illian so you can find your husband."

"ə dil," sɛɾəl sɛd. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd. "ði . . . ʌðɝz ɑɹ ɡɔn, ðɛn?"

"A deal," Setalle said. She hesitated, glancing northward. "The . . . others are gone, then?"

"jɛs." ɡʊd ɹɪɾəns.

"Yes." Good riddance.

ʃi nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ ɹɪɡɹɛtfəl. meɪbi ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ɪz mɛn əbaʊt fəɹ lʌntʃ kəz ʃi hæd bɪn əfɛndəɾ ət siɪŋ əm ɹɪlæks. meɪbi ʃi hæd bɪn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə bɪzi hɝsɛlf æt.

She nodded, looking regretful. Maybe she had not been ordering his men about for lunch because she had been offended at seeing them relax. Maybe she had been looking for something to busy herself at.

"aɪm sɑɹi," mæt sɛd. "əbaʊt wʌtɛvɝ hæpən tə ju."

"I'm sorry," Mat said. "About whatever happened to you."

"ðə pæst ɪz ɡɔn," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "æn aɪ nid tə liv ɪt bi. aɪ ʃoʊl" nɛvɝ əv ivən æsk tə si ði aɪɾəm jə wɛɹ. ðiz læs fju wiks əv meɪd mi fɝɡɛt maɪsɛlf."

"The past is gone," she replied. "And I need to leave it be. I shoal" never have even asked to see the item you wear. These last few weeks have made me forget myself."

mæt nɑɾəd, pɑɹɾɪŋ wɪð hɝ, ðən wɛn sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ oʊlvɝ. ən æftɝ ðæt, hi ɹɪli ʃəd ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn tə tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪz koʊt. ən bɝn hɪm, hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ʃeɪv, tu.

Mat nodded, parting with her, then went searching for Olver. And after that, he really should get around to changing his coat. And burn him, he was going to shave, too.

ðə mɛn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɪm kəd blʌɾi kɪl ɪm ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd. ə slɪt θɹoʊt wəd bi bɛɾɝ ðən ðɪs ɪtʃɪŋ.

The men looking for him could bloody kill him if they wanted. A slit throat would be better than this itching.

ɪleɪn stʃɹoʊl θɹu ðə pæləsəz sʌnɹaɪz ɡɑɹɾən. ðɪs smɔlɝ ɡɑɹɾən hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə feɪvɝd loʊkeɪʃən ə hɝ mʌðɝz, sɛɾ ətɑp ðə ɹuf ə ðə leɪsəz istɝn wɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɹɪm baɪ ən oʊvəl ʌv waɪt stoʊnwɝk, wɪð ə lɑɹdʒɝ, kɝvd wɔl ət ðə bæk.

Elayne strolled through the palace's Sunrise Garden. This smaller garden had always been a favored location of her mother's, set atop the roof of the lace's eastern wing. It was rimmed by an oval of white stonework, with a larger, curved wall at the back.

ɪleɪn hæɾ ə fʊl vju ʌv ðə sɪɾi bɪloʊ. ɪn ɝliɝ jɪɹz, ʃi hæd laɪk ðə loʊɝ ɡɑɹɾənz pɹɪsaɪsli kəz ðeɪ wɝ ə ɹitʃɹit. ɪt wɑz ɪn ðoʊz ɡɑɹɾənz ðət ʃi hæd fɝs mɛt ɹænd. ʃi pɹɛst ə hæn tə hɝ bɛli. ðoʊ ʃi fɛlt ɪnɔɹməs, ðə pɹɛɡnənsi wɑz oʊnli dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ.

Elayne had a full view of the city below. In earlier years, she had liked the lower gardens precisely because they were a retreat. It was in those gardens that she had first met Rand. She pressed a hand to her belly. Though she felt enormous, the pregnancy was only just beginning to show.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃid hæd tə kəmɪʃən ən ɪntaɪɝli nu sɛɾ ʌv ɡaʊnz. ʃi wəd pɹɑbli hæv tə də soʊ əɡɛn ɪn ðə kʌmɪŋ mʌnθs. wʌɾ ə bɑðɝ.

Unfortunately, she'd had to commission an entirely new set of gowns. She would probably have to do so again in the coming months. What a bother.

Elayne continued to walk the roof garden. Pink jumpups and white morningstars bloomed in planters. The blossoms weren't nearly as large as they should have been, and already they were wilting. The gardeners complained that nothing helped. Outside the city, grass and weeds were dying in swaths, and the patchwork quilt of fields and crops looked depressingly brown. It is coming, Elayne thought. She continued on her way, walking a path made of springy grass, manicured and kept short. The gardeners' efforts weren't without some results. The grass here was mostly green, and the air smelled of the roses that wove their way up the sides of the wall. Those had brown spots on them, but they had bloomed.

"We spoke of this," Alise said carefully, eyes narrowing. "We will b come associated with the Tower, a place for Aes Sedai to retire."

"ʃʊɹli jəl nɑt muv tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðoʊ. wʌt ɡʊd wəd tieɪtʃ kɪn bi əz ə pleɪs tə ɹɪtaɪɹ fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑlətɪks ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ soʊ nɪɹ tieɪtʃ waɪt taʊɝ?"

"Surely you will not move to Tar Valon, though. What good would th Kin be as a place to retire from Aes Sedai politics if they are so near th White Tower?"

"wi hæɾ əsumd wi wəd ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ," æləz sɛd.

"We had assumed we would remain here," Alise said.

"ðæt wɑz maɪ əsʌmpʃən əz wɛl," ɪleɪn sɛd kɛɹfəli. "bʌɾ əsəmp-. ʃənz ɑɹ wik. aɪ wɪʃ tə ɡɪv jə pɹɑməsəz ɪnstɛd. æftɝ ɔl, ɪf jə wɝ tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, aɪ si noʊ ɹizən tə nɑɾ ɔfɝ jə səpɔɹt dɝɛkli fɹəm ðə kɹaʊn."

"æt wʌt kɑst?" æləz æskt. sumeɪkoʊ wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð ə kənfjuz fɹaʊn.

"Not much of one," Elayne said. "Really, not a cost at all. An occasional favor, as you have done the Crown in the past."

ðə ɡɑɹɾən fɛl stɪl. feɪn kɔlz fɹəm ðə sɪɾi bɪloʊ ɹoʊz ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ən ðə bɹæntʃəz ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ə fju bɹaʊn livz bɪtwin ɪleɪn ən ðə kɪn.

The garden fell still. Faint calls from the city below rose up into the air, and the branches shivered in the wind, dropping a few brown leaves between Elayne and the Kin.

"ðæt saʊnz deɪnʒɝəs," æləz sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə sɪp ə hɝ ti. "ʃʊɹli jəɹ nɑt sədʒɛstɪŋ ðət wi sɛɾ ʌp ə ɹaɪvəl waɪt taʊɝ hɪɹ, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn."

"That sounds dangerous," Alise said, taking a sip of her tea. "Surely you're not suggesting that we set up a rival White Tower here, in Caemlyn."

"nʌθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt," ɪleɪn sɛd kwɪkli. "aɪ æm ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪsɛlf, æftɝ ɔl. ən ɛɡwin əz spoʊkən ə lɛɾɪŋ ðə kɪn kəntɪnju əz ðeɪv bɪfɔɹ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ æksɛpt əɹ əθɔɹəɾi."

"Nothing of the sort," Elayne said quickly. "I am Aes Sedai myself, after all. And Egwene has spoken of letting the Kin continue as they have before, so long as they accept her authority."

"aɪm nɑt sɝɾən wi wɑnə 'kəntɪnju əz wɪv bɪfɔɹ,'" æləz sɛd. "ðə waɪt taʊɝ lɛft əs tə lɪv əɹ laɪvz ɪn tɛɹɝ ðət wi wəd bi dɪskʌvɝd. bʌɾ ɔl ðə waɪl, ðeɪ wɝ juzɪŋ ʌs. ðə mɔɹ wi kənsɪɾɝ ðæt, ðə lɛs . . . əmjuz ðət meɪks ʌs."

"I'm not certain we want to 'continue as we have before,'" Alise said. "The White Tower left us to live our lives in terror that we would be discovered. But all the while, they were using us. The more we consider that, the less . . . amused that makes us."

"spik fəɹ jɝsɛlf, æləz," sumeɪkoʊ sɛd. "aɪ ɪntɛn tə bi tɛstəɾ ən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ. əl dʒɔɪn ðə jɛloʊ, mɑɹk maɪ wɝdz."

"Speak for yourself, Alise," Sumeko said. "I intend to be tested and return to the Tower. I will join the Yellow, mark my words."

"pɝhæps, bʌt ðeɪ woʊn əv mi," æləz sɛd. "aɪm tu wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ. aɪ woʊn æksɛp səm hæfweɪ mɛʒɝ, fɔɹs tə skɹeɪp ən baʊ ɛvɹi taɪm ə sɪstɝ kʌmz əlɔŋ ən wɑns mi tə wɑʃ əɹ kloʊðɪŋ. bʌɾ aɪ woʊn stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ, iðɝ. aɪ woʊnt ɡɪv ɪɾ ʌp. ɛɡwin sədaɪ hæz spoʊkən ə lɛɾɪŋ ðə kɪn kəntɪnju, bʌɾ ɪf wi du, wəd bi wi bi eɪbəl tə wɝk ðə wʌn paʊɝ oʊpənli?"

"Perhaps, but they won't have me," Alise said. "I'm too weak in the Power. I won't accept some halfway measure, forced to scrape and bow every time a sister comes along and wants me to wash her clothing. But I won't stop channeling, either. I won't give it up. Egwene Sedai has spoken of letting the Kin continue, but if we do, would be we be able to work the One Power openly?"

"aɪ əsum jə wəd bi eɪbəl tə," ɪleɪn sɛd. "mʌtʃ ə ðɪs wɑz ɛɡwinz aɪdiə. ʃi sɝɾənli wʊdn sɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ tə jə tə ɹɪtaɪɹ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə bi fɔɹbɪɾən tə tʃænəl. noʊ, ðə deɪz ʌv wɪmən aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ tʃænəlɪŋ ɪn sikɹəɾ əv pæst. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ði il waɪz wʌnz, hæv pɹuvən ðət taɪmz mʌs tʃeɪnʒ."

"I assume you would be able to," Elayne said. "Much of this was Egwene's idea. She certainly wouldn't send Aes Sedai to you to retire if they were to be forbidden to channel. No, the days of women outside the Tower channeling in secret have passed. The Windfinders, the Aiel Wise Ones, have proven that times must change."

"pɝhæps," æləz sɛd. "bʌt ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ sɝvəsəz tə ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ ɪz ə vɛɹi dɪfɹən mæɾɝ."

"perhaps," Alise said. "But giving our services to the Crown of Andor is a very different matter."

"wi wəd meɪk sɝɾən nɑt tə kəmpit wɪð ðə taʊɝz ɪntʃɹəsts," flævn sɛd. "æn jə wəɾ æksɛp ði eɪmɹlɪnz əθɔɹəɾi. soʊ wʌɾ ɪz ðə ɹɑbləm? ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹəvaɪd sɝvəs tə mɑnɑɹks əkɹɔs ðə lænd."

"We would make certain not to compete with the Tower's interests," Flavne said. "And you would accept the Aymrlin's authority. So what is the roblem? Aes Sedai provide service to monarchs across the land."

æləz sɪpt əɹ ti. "jɔɹ ɔfɝ əz mɛɹət. bʌɾ ɪt dɪpɛnz ɑn ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðə feɪvɝz ɹikwaɪɝd baɪ ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ."

Alise sipped her tea. "Your offer has merit. But it depends on the nature of the favors required by the Crown of Andor."

"aɪ wəɾ oʊnli æsk tu θɪŋz ə ju," ɪleɪn sɛd. "tʃɹævlɪŋ ən hilɪŋ. jə nid nɑɾ ɛntɝ əɹ kɑnflɪks, jə nid nɑt bi pɑɹɾ ʌv əɹ pɑlətɪks. sɪmpli əɡɹi tə hil maɪ pipəl u ɑɹ sɪk, ən tə əsaɪn ə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən itʃ deɪ tə kɹieɪt ɡeɪtweɪz wən ðə kɹaʊn wɪʃɪz."

"I would only ask two things of you," Elayne said. "Traveling and Healing. You need not enter our conflicts, you need not be part of our politics. Simply agree to Heal my people who are sick, and to assign a group of women each day to create gateways when the crown wishes."

"ðæt stɪl saʊnz ən ɑfəl lɑt laɪk jəɹ oʊn waɪt taʊɝ," æləz sɛd. sumeɪkoʊ wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"That still sounds an awful lot like your own White Tower," Alise said. Sumeko was frowning.

"noʊ, noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðə waɪt taʊɝ minz əθɔɹəɾi, pɑlətɪks. jə wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli. ɪmædʒən ə pleɪs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn wɛɹ ɛni pɝsən kən kʌm tə ɹəsiv hilɪŋ, fɹi ʌv tʃɑɹdʒ.

"No, no," Elayne said. "The White Tower means authority, politics. You would be something else entirely. Imagine a place in Caemlyn where any person can come to receive Healing, free of charge.

ɪmædʒən ə sɪɾi fɹi ʌv dɪziz. ɪmædʒən ə wɝld wɛɹ fud kən tʃɹævəl ɪnstənli tə ðoʊz u niɾ ɪt."

Imagine a city free of disease. Imagine a world where food can travel instantly to those who need it."

"æn ə kwin u kən sɛn tʃɹups wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi nidz," æləz sɛd. "huz soʊlʒɝz kən faɪt wʌn deɪ, ðən bi fɹi ʌv wunz ðə nɛkst. ə kwin u kən ɝn ə taɪɾi pɹɑfət baɪ tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ mɝtʃəns fəɹ æksɛs tə hɝ ɡeɪtweɪz." ʃi tʊk ə sɪp ə hɝ ti.

"And a queen who can send troops wherever she needs," Alise said. "Whose soldiers can fight one day, then be free of wounds the next. A queen who can earn a tidy profit by charging merchants for access to her gateways." She took a sip of her tea.

"jɛs," ɪleɪn ədmɪɾəd. ðoʊ ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ ʃi wɑz gɑnə kənvɪns ɛɡwin tə lɛɾ əɹ də ðət pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt.

"Yes," Elayne admitted. Though she wasn't certain how she was going to convince Egwene to let her do that part of it.

"wi wɪl wɑn hæf," æləz sɛd. "hæf ʌv ɛniθɪŋ jə tʃɑɹdʒ fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ əɹ hilɪŋ."

"We will want half," Alise said. "Half of anything you charge for Traveling or Healing."

hilɪŋ ɪz fɹi," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli. "fɔɹ ɛniwʌn u kʌmz, ɹəɡɑɹdləs əɹ steɪʃən. pipəl ɑɹ tʃɹiɾəd ɪn ɔɹɾɝ ə ðə sɪvɛɹɪɾi ʌv ðɛɹ eɪlmənt, nɑɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ ə ðɛɹ ɹæŋk."

Healing is free," Elayne said firmly. "For anyone who comes, regardless or station. People are treated in order of the severity of their ailment, not in order of their rank."

"aɪ kəɾ əɡɹi tə ðɪs," æləz sɛd.

"I could agree to this," Alise said.

sumeɪkoʊ tɝn tə hɝ, aɪz waɪd. "ju kænɑt spik fəɹ ʌs. jə jɝsɛlf θɹu ɪn maɪ feɪs ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl hævɪŋ dɪzɑlvd, naʊ ðət wɪv lɛft ɛbu dɑɹ. bɪsaɪdz, baɪ ðə ɹul - "aɪ spik oʊnli fəɹ maɪsɛlf, sumeɪkoʊ," æləz sɛd. "æn ðoʊz u wəd mi. ðə kɪn əz wi nu ðɛm ɑɹ noʊ mɔɹ. wi wɝ dɑməneɪɾəd baɪ əɹ nid tə ɹɪmeɪn sikɹət, ən ðəɾ ɪz ɡɔn naʊ."

Sumeko turned to her, eyes wide. "You cannot speak for us. You yourself threw in my face the Knitting Circle having dissolved, now that we have left Ebou Dar. Besides, by the Rule - "I speak only for myself, Sumeko," Alise said. "And those who would me. The Kin as we knew them are no more. We were dominated by our need to remain secret, and that is gone now."

sumeɪkoʊ ɡɹu saɪlənt.

Sumeko grew silent.

"ju min tə dʒɔɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, maɪ fɹɛnd," æləz sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm. "bʌt ðəl nɑɾ əv mi, nɔɹ wɪl aɪ hæv ðɛm. aɪ nid sɔɹn θɪŋ ɛls, ən ʌðɝz wɪl əz wɛl."

"You mean to join the Aes Sedai, my friend," Alise said, laying a hand on her arm. "But they will not have me, nor will I have them. I need sorn thing else, and others will as well."

"bʌt tə taɪ jʊɹsɛlvz tə ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ. . . ."

"But to tie yourselves to the Crown of Andor. . . ."

"wi taɪ aʊɝsɛlvz tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ," æləz sɛd. "bʌt lɪv ɪn keɪɛm-lɪn. boʊθ əv ðɛɹ bɛnəfɪts. wi ɑɹən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stæn ɑn əɹ oʊn ændɝ ɪz əz ɡʊɾ ə pleɪs əz ɛni. ɪts ðə feɪvɝ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðə feɪvɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. moʊsli, ɪts hɪɹ, ən soʊ ɑɹ wi."

"We tie ourselves to the White Tower," Alise said. "But live in Caem-lyn. Both have their benefits. We aren't strong enough to stand on our own Andor is as good a place as any. It has the favor of the White Tower, and the favor of the Dragon Reborn. Mostly, it is here, and so are we."

"ju kən ɹiɔɹɡənaɪz," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪksaɪɾəd. "ðə ɹul kən bi kɹæftɪɾ ənu. jə kən dɪsaɪd tə lɛt kɪn mɛɹi naʊ, ɪf jə wɪʃ. aɪ θɪŋk ðət wəd bi fəɹ ðə bɛst."

"You can reorganize," Elayne said, growing excited. "The Rule can be crafted anew. You can decide to let Kin marry now, if you wish. I think that would be for the best."

"waɪ?" æləz æskt.

"Why?" Alise asked.

"bɪkɔz ɪɾəl taɪ ðɛm daʊn," ɪleɪn ɪkspleɪnd. "ðæt wɪl meɪk əm lɛs ʌv ə θɹɛt tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɪɾəl hɛlp dɪfɝɛnʃieɪt ju. ɪts sʌmθɪŋ ðət fju wɪmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ du, ən ɪt ɡɪvz jə sʌmθɪŋ tə meɪk ðə kɪn mɔɹ ətʃɹæktɪv əz ən ɑpʃən."

"Because it will tie them down," Elayne explained. "That will make them less of a threat to the White Tower. It will help differentiate you. It is something that few women in the White Tower do, and it gives you something to make the Kin more attractive as an option."

æləz nɑɾəd, θɔtfəl; sumeɪkoʊ sim tə bi kʌmɪŋ ɝaʊnd. ɪleɪn wɑz sɑɹi tə ədmɪt ðət ʃi wʊdn mɪs ðə wʊmən wən ʃi lɛft. ɪleɪn ɪntɛndəd tə pʊʃ əm tə ɹistʃɹʌktʃɝ haʊ ðeɪ tʃoʊz liɾɝz. ɪt wəd bi mʌtʃ mɔɹ kənvinjən ɪf ʃi kəd wɝk wɪð wʌn laɪk æləz, əz əpoʊz tə humɛvɝ hæpən tə bi ði oʊldəst əmʌŋ ðɛm.

Alise nodded, thoughtful; Sumeko seemed to be coming around. Elayne was sorry to admit that she wouldn't miss the woman when she left. Elayne intended to push them to restructure how they chose leaders. It would be much more convenient if she could work with one like Alise, as opposed to whomever happened to be the oldest among them.

"aɪ stɪl wɝi əbaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn," æləz sɛd. "ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑt tʃɑɹdʒ fəɹ sɝvəsəz. wʌt wɪl ʃi seɪ ɪf wi stɑɹt duɪŋ soʊ?"

"I still worry about the Amyrlin," Alise said. "Aes Sedai do not charge for services. What will she say if we start doing so?"

"aɪ wɪl spik wɪð ɛɡwin," ɪleɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd. "aɪm sɝɾən aɪ kən kənvɪns əɹ ðət ðə kɪn, ən ændɝ, ɑɹ noʊ θɹɛt tə hɝ."

"I will speak with Egwene," Elayne repeated. "I'm certain I can convince her that the Kin, and Andor, are no threat to her."

hoʊpfəli. ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃæns fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ɪn ðə kɪn, ə tʃæns fəɹ ændɝ tə hæv kɑnstən ən ɪnɪkspɛnsɪv æksɛs tə ɡeɪtweɪz. ðət wəd pʊɾ əɹ ɑn nɪɹli ikwəl ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ðə sintʃæn.

Hopefully. There was a chance for something incredible in the Kin, a chance for Andor to have constant and inexpensive access to gateways. That would put her on nearly equal ground with the Seanchan.

ʃi spoʊk wɪð ðə wɪmən fəɹ ə taɪm lɔŋɡɝ, meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðeɪ fɛlt ʃi wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ əm du ətɛnʃən. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi dɪsmɪs ðɛm, bʌt faʊn hɝsɛlf lɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən, stændɪŋ bɪtwin tu plæntɝz hoʊldɪŋ bluɪbɛlz, ðɛɹ klʌstɝz ə taɪni, væsəlaɪk blɑsəmz dʒɹupɪŋ ən wɪɡəlɪŋ ɪn ðə bɹiz. ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə plæntɝ bɪsaɪd ðɛm, wɪtʃ wɑz ɛmpti. ðə bluɪbɛlz ðəɹ hæd flaʊɝɾ ɪn ðə kʌlɝ ə blʌd, ən hæɾ æktʃəli  blɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɹɛd wən kʌt. ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz hæd pʊld əm aʊt.

She spoke with the women for a time longer, making certain they felt she was giving them due attention. Eventually, she dismissed them, but found herself lingering in the garden, standing between two planters holding bluebells, their clusters of tiny, vaselike blossoms drooping and wiggling in the breeze. She tried not to look at the planter beside them, which was empty. The bluebells there had flowered in the color of blood, and had actually bled something red when cut. The gardeners had pulled them out.

ðə sintʃæn wəd kʌm fəɹ ændɝ ɪvɛntʃəwəli. baɪ ðɛn, ɹændz ɑɹmiz wəd laɪkli bi wikən ən bɹoʊkən fɹəm ðə faɪɾɪŋ, ðɛɹ liɾɝ pɑsəbli dɛd. əɡɛn, ɪt meɪɾ əɹ hɑɹt twɪs tə kənsɪɾɝ ðæt, bʌt ʃi kʊdnt ʃaɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðə tʃɹuθ.

The Seanchan would come for Andor eventually. By then, Rands armies would likely be weakened and broken from the fighting, their leader possibly dead. Again, it made her heart twist to consider that, but she couldn't shy away from the truth.

ændɝ wəd bi ə pɹaɪz tə ðə sintʃæn. ðə maɪnz ən ɹɪtʃ lænz ɑɾ əɹ ɹɛlm wəd tɛmp ðɛm, əz wəd ðə pɹɑksɪməɾi tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi səspɛktəd ðət ðoʊz u kleɪm tə bi ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz sʌk-sɛsɝz wəd nɛvɝ bi sæɾəsfaɪd əntɪl ðeɪ hɛld ɔl ðət hæd wʌns bɪlɔŋ tə ðɛɹ ænsɛstɝ.

Andor would be a prize to the Seanchan. The mines and rich lands ot her realm would tempt them, as would the proximity to Tar Valon. Beyond that, she suspected that those who claimed to be Artur Hawkwing's suc-cessors would never be satisfied until they held all that had once belonged to their ancestor.

ɪleɪn lʊkt aʊɾ oʊvɝ əɹ neɪʃən. hɝ neɪʃən. fʊl ə ðoʊz u tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɪn əɹ tə pɹətɛkt ən dɪfɛn ðɛm. mɛni hu hæd səpɔɹɾəd əɹ kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn hæd hæd lɪɾəl feɪθ ɪn hɝ. bʌt ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ bɛst ɑp-ʃən ðɛɹ oʊnli ɑpʃən. ʃi wəd ʃoʊ ðɛm ðə wɪzdəm ə ðɛɹ tʃɔɪs.

Elayne looked out over her nation. Her nation. Full of those who trusted in her to protect and defend them. Many who had supported her claim to the throne had had little faith in her. But she was their best op-tion their only option. She would show them the wisdom of their choice.

sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ðə kɪn wəd bi wʌn stɛp. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðə sintʃæn wəd bi eɪbəl tə tʃɹævəl. ɔl ðeɪ niɾəd tə də wɑz kæptʃɝ wʌn wʊmən u nu ðə wivz, ən sun itʃ ən ɛvɹi deɪmeɪn wɪð ðə ɹɛkwəzət stʃɹɛŋkθ wəd bi eɪbəl tə kɹieɪt ðə pɔɹɾəlz. ɪleɪn niɾəd æksɛs tə ðɛm əz wɛl.

Securing the Kin would be one step. Sooner or later, the Seanchan would be able to Travel. All they needed to do was capture one woman who knew the weaves, and soon each and every damane with the requisite strength would be able to create the portals. Elayne needed access to them as well.

wʌt ʃi dɪdn hæv, haʊɛvɝ, wɝ tʃænlɝz tə juz ɪn bæɾəl. ʃi nu ʃi kʊdn æsk ðɪs ə ðə kɪn. ðeɪd nɛvɝ əɡɹi tə ɪt, nɔɹ wəɾ ɛɡwin. nɔɹ wəɾ ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf. fɔɹsɪŋ ə wʊmən tə juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən wəd meɪk əɹ noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ðə sintʃæn ðɛmsɛlvz.

What she didn't have, however, were channelers to use in battle. She knew she couldn't ask this of the Kin. They'd never agree to it, nor would Egwene. Nor would Elayne herself. Forcing a woman to use the Power as a weapon would make her no better than the Seanchan themselves.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɪleɪn nu fʊl wɛl ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən wɪmən juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəd kɑz.

Unfortunately, Elayne knew full well the destruction women using the One Power could cause.

ʃid bɪn baʊn ɪn ə wæɡən waɪl bɝdʒɪt lɛd ði ətæk ɑn ðə blæk ədʒɑ hu hæd kɪdnæpt əɹ hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt ʃid sin ɪts æftɝmæθ. hʌnʒɹədz dɛd, hʌnʒɹədz mɔɹ wundəd, dʌzənz bɝn əweɪ. smoʊkɪŋ, twɪstəd kɔɹpsəz.

She'd been bound in a wagon while Birgitte led the attack on the Black Ajah who had kidnapped her here in Caemlyn, but she'd seen its aftermath. Hundreds dead, hundreds more wounded, dozens burned away. Smoking, twisted corpses.

ʃi niɾəd sʌmθɪŋ. ən ɛdʒ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. sʌmθɪŋ tə bæləns ðɛɹ tʃænlɝz ɪn kɑmbæt. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv wɑz ðə blæk taʊɝ. ɪt wɑz ɑn ændɝz sɔɪl. ʃid toʊld əm ðət ʃi kənsɪɾɝd əm pɑɹɾ ə hɝ neɪʃən, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ ʃid ɡɔn noʊ fɝðɝ ðən sɛndɪŋ ɪnspɛkʃən pɑɹɾiz.

She needed something. An edge against the Seanchan. Something to balance their channelers in combat. The only thing she could think of was the Black Tower. It was on Andor's soil. She'd told them that she considered them part of her nation, but so far she'd gone no further than sending inspection parties.

wʌt wəd hæpən tə ðɛm ɪf ɹænd daɪd? dɛɹd ʃi tʃɹaɪ tə kleɪm ðɛm? dɛɹd ʃi weɪt fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls tə?

What would happen to them if Rand died? Dared she try to claim them? Dared she wait for someone else to?


tʃæptɝ eɪtin


CHAPTER 18

ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðɪs pleɪs


The Strength of This Place

pɛɹɪn ɹæn θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs. tʃɹeɪlz ʌv wɔɾɝi mɪs bɹʌʃt ɪz feɪs ən kəndɛnst ɪn ɪz bɪɹd. hɪz maɪnd wɑz fɑɡi, dɪstənt. wɛɹ wɑz i ɡoʊɪŋ? wʌt wɑz i duɪŋ? waɪ wɑz i ɹʌnɪŋ?

Perrin ran through the darkness. Trails of watery mist brushed his face and condensed in his beard. His mind was foggy, distant. Where was he going? What was he doing? Why was he running?

hi ɹɔɹɾ ən tʃɑɹdʒd, ɹɪpɪŋ θɹu ðə veɪl dɑɹknəs ən bɝstɪŋ ɪndə oʊpən ɛɹ. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən lændəɾ ɑn ðə tɑp ʌv ə stip hɪl kʌvɝd wɪð ʃɔɹt, pætʃi ɡɹæs, wɪð ə ɹɪŋ ə tʃɹiz əɾ ɪts beɪs. ðə skaɪ ɹʌmbəld ən tʃɝnd wɪð klaʊdz, laɪk ə bɔɪlɪŋ pɑɾ ə tɑɹ.

He roared and charged, ripping through the veiled darkness and bursting into open air. He took a deep breath and landed on the top of a steep hill covered with short, patchy grass, with a ring of trees at its base. The sky rumbled and churned with clouds, like a boiling pot of tar.

hi wɑz ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. hɪz bɑɾi slʌmbɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, ɑn ðɪs hɪltɑp, wɪð feɪl. hi smaɪld, bɹiðɪŋ dipli. hɪz pɹɑbləmz hæd nɑt dɪmɪnɪʃt. ɪn fækt, wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊk ʌltəmeɪɾəm, ðeɪ simd mæɡnəfaɪd. bʌɾ ɔl wɑz wɛl wɪð feɪl. ðət sɪmpəl fæk tʃeɪnʒd soʊ mʌtʃ. wɪð əɹ əɾ ɪz saɪd, hi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ.

He was in the wolf dream. His body slumbered in the real world, on this hilltop, with Faile. He smiled, breathing deeply. His problems had not diminished. In fact, with the Whitecloak ultimatum, they seemed magnified. But all was well with Faile. That simple fact changed so much. With her at his side, he could do anything.

hi lɛp daʊn fɹəm ðə hɪlsaɪɾ ən kɹɔs ði oʊpən ɛɹiə wɛɹ ɪz ɑɹmi kæmpt. ðeɪ hæd bɪn hɪɹ lɔŋ ɪnʌf ðət saɪnz hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. tɛns ɹəflɛktəd ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld, ðoʊ ðɛɹ flæps wɝ ɪn ə dɪfɹən pəzɪʃən itʃ taɪm i lʊkt ət ðɛm. kʊk-faɪɝ pɪts ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹʌts ɪn ðə pæθweɪz, əkeɪʒənəl bɪts ə ɹɛfjus əɹ dɪskɑɹɾɪd tulz. ðiz wəd pɑp ɪndə ɛɡzɪstəns, ðən vænɪʃ.

He leaped down from the hillside and crossed the open area where his army camped. They had been here long enough that signs had appeared in the wolf dream. Tents reflected the waking world, though their flaps were in a different position each time he looked at them. Cook-fire pits in the ground, ruts in the pathways, occasional bits of refuse or discarded tools. These would pop into existence, then vanish.

hi muv kwɪkli θɹu ðə kæmp, itʃ stɛp teɪkɪŋ ɪm tɛn peɪsɪz. wʌns i maɪɾ əv faʊn ðə læk ə pipəl ɪn ðə kæmp ɪɹi, bʌɾ i wɑz əkʌstəm tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim naʊ. ðɪs wɑz nætʃɹəl.

He moved quickly through the camp, each step taking him ten paces. Once he might have found the lack of people in the camp eerie, but he was accustomed to the wolf dream now. This was natural.

pɛɹɪn əpɹoʊtʃt ðə stætʃu ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp, ðən lʊkt ʌp ət ði eɪdʒ-pɑk stoʊn, oʊvɝɡɹoʊn wɪð laɪkən ə blæk, ɔɹənʒ ən ɡɹin. ðə stætʃu mʌst əv bɪn poʊzd ɑdli, ɪf ɪt hæd fɔlən ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ. ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn kɹieɪɾəd ðɪs weɪ - ən ɪnɔɹməs ɑɹm bɝstɪŋ fɹəm ðə loʊm.

Perrin approached the statue at the side of the camp, then looked up at the age-pocked stone, overgrown with lichen of black, orange and green. The statue must have been posed oddly, if it had fallen in such a way. It almost looked as if it had been created this way - an enormous arm bursting from the loam.

pɛɹɪn tɝn tə ðə saʊθist, təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðə waɪtkloʊk kæmp wəd bi faʊnd. hi hæd tə dil wɪð ðɛm. hi wɑz ɪnkɹisɪŋli sɝɾən -  nfɪɾənt, ivən - ðəɾ i kəd nɑt kəntɪnju əntɪl i hæd kənfɹʌntəd ðiz ʃædoʊz fɹəm ðə pæst.

Perrin turned to the southeast, toward where the Whitecloak camp would be found. He had to deal with them. He was increasingly certain -  nfident, even - that he could not continue until he had confronted these shadows from the past.

ðəɹ wɑz wʌn weɪ tə dil wɪð əm fəɹ sɝɾən. ə kɛɹfəl tʃɹæp juzɪŋ ði æʃəmən ən waɪz wʌnz, ən pɛɹɪn kəd hɪt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðeɪ ʃæɾɝd. hi kəd meɪbi ivən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm pɝmənənli əz ə ɡɹup.

There was one way to deal with them for certain. A careful trap using the Asha'man and Wise Ones, and Perrin could hit the Children so hard that they shattered. He could maybe even destroy them permanently as a group.

hi hæd ðə minz, ði ɑpɝtunəɾi, ən ðə moʊɾəveɪʃən. noʊ mɔɹ fɪɹ ɪn ðə lænd, noʊ mɔɹ waɪtkloʊk mɑk tʃɹaɪəlz. hi lɛp fɔɹwɝd, sɔɹɪŋ θɝɾi fiɾ ən fɔlɪŋ laɪtli tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðən i tʊk ɔf, ɹʌnɪŋ saʊθist əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd.

He had the means, the opportunity, and the motivation. No more fear in the land, no more Whitecloak mock trials. He leaped forward, soaring thirty feet and falling lightly to the ground. Then he took off, running southeast along the road.

hi faʊn ðə waɪtkloʊk kæmp ɪn ə fɔɹəstəd hɑloʊ, θaʊzənz ʌv waɪt tɛns sɛɾ ʌp ɪn taɪt ɹɪŋz.

He found the Whitecloak camp in a forested hollow, thousands of white tents set up in tight rings.

ðə tɛns ə səm tɛn θaʊzən tʃɪlʒɹən, əlɔŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ tɛn θaʊzən mɝsənɛɹiz ən ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz. beɪlwɝ ɛstəmeɪɾəd ðət ðɪs wɑz ðə bʌlk ə ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən, ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn ənklɪɹ ɑn haʊ hid ɡɑɾən ðət nɑlədʒ. hoʊpfəli ðə dʌsti mænz heɪtʃɹəɾ ə ðə waɪtkloʊks wɑzn klaʊɾɪŋ ɪz dʒʌdʒmənt.

The tents of some ten thousand Children, along with another ten thousand mercenaries and other soldiers. Balwer estimated that this was the bulk of the remaining Children, though he had been unclear on how he'd gotten that knowledge. Hopefully the dusty man's hatred of the Whitecloaks wasn't clouding his judgment.

pɛɹɪn muvd əmʌŋ ðə tɛns, lʊkɪŋ tə si ɪf i kəd dɪskʌvɝ ɛniθɪŋ ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs ən ði il hæd nɑt. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli, bʌɾ i fɪɡjɝɾ ɪt wɑz wɝθ ən ətɛmpt, waɪl i wɑz hɪɹ. bɪsaɪdz, hi wɑntəd tə si ðə pleɪs wɪð ɪz oʊn aɪz. hi lɪftəd flæps, muv bɪtwin ɡɹupɪŋz ə tɛns, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə pleɪs ən ɡɛɾɪŋ ə fil fəɹ ɪɾ ən ɪts ɑkjəpəns. ðə kæmp wɑz ɝeɪnʒd ɪn ə vɛɹi ɔɹɾɝli mænɝ. ði ɪnsaɪdz wɝ lɛs steɪbəl ðən ðə tɛns ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt wʌɾ i sɔ wɑz ɔlsoʊ kɛpt ɔɹɾɝli.

Perrin moved among the tents, looking to see if he could discover anything that Elyas and the Aiel had not. It was unlikely, but he figured it was worth an attempt, while he was here. Besides, he wanted to see the place with his own eyes. He lifted flaps, moved between groupings of tents, inspecting the place and getting a feel for it and its occupants. The camp was arranged in a very orderly manner. The insides were less stable than the tents themselves, but what he saw was also kept orderly.

ðə waɪtkloʊks laɪk θɪŋz nit, taɪɾi ən kɛɹfəli foʊldəd. ən ðeɪ laɪk tə pɹitɛn ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝl kəd bi pɑlɪʃt ʌp ən klin ðə seɪm weɪ, pipəl dɪfaɪn ən ɪkspleɪn ɪn wʌn əɹ tu wɝdz.

The Whitecloaks liked things neat, tidy and carefully folded. And they liked to pretend the entire world could be polished up and cleaned the same way, people defined and explained in one or two words.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ tə ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmænd-ɝz tɛnt. ði ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ə ðə tɛns lɛɾ ɪm tə ɪɾ izəli, ət ðə sɛntɝ ɹɪŋ, ɪt wɑzn mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ tɛns, ən pɛɹɪn dʌkt ɪnsaɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si ɪf i kəd faɪn ɛniθɪŋ ə jus. ɪt wɑz fɝnɪʃt sɪmpli, wɪð ə bɛd-ðæt wɑz ɪn ə dɪfɹən pəzɪʃən itʃ taɪm pɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ ɪt, əlɔŋ wɪð ə teɪbəl hoʊldɪŋ ɑbʒɛkts ðət vænɪʃt ən əpɪɹɾ ət ɹændəm.

Perrin shook his head, making his way to the Lord Captain Command-er's tent. The organization of the tents led him to it easily, at the center ring, It wasn't much larger than the other tents, and Perrin ducked inside, trying to see if he could find anything of use. It was furnished simply, with a bed-that was in a different position each time Perrin looked at it, along with a table holding objects that vanished and appeared at random.

pɛɹɪn stɛpt ʌp tə ɪt, pɪkɪŋ ʌp sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ əpɪɹd ðɛɹ. ə sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ. hi dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə sɪɡnɪt, ə wɪŋ dæɡɝ, bʌt mɛmoʊ- ɹaɪzd ɪt dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɪŋ vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, tu tʃɹænʒən tə steɪ lɔŋ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ðoʊ hid mɛt wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊk liɾɝ, ən kɔɹəspɑndɪd wɪð ðə mæn, hi dɪdnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðə mænz pæs pɝhæps ðɪs wəd hɛlp.

Perrin stepped up to it, picking up something that appeared there. A signet ring. He didn't recognize the signet, a winged dagger, but memo- rised it just before the ring vanished from his fingers, too transient to stay long in the wolf dream. Though he'd met with the Whitecloak leader, and corresponded with the man, he didn't know much about the man's past Perhaps this would help.

hi sɝtʃt θɹu ðə tɛn ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ, faɪndɪŋ nʌθɪŋ ə jus, ðən wɛn tə ðə lɑɹdʒ tɛnt wɛɹ ɡɔl hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ðət mɛni ʌv ðə kæptɪvz wɝ biɪŋ kɛpt. hɪɹ, hi sɔ mæstɝ ɡɪlz hæɾ əpɪɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən vænɪʃ.

He searched through the tent a while longer, finding nothing of use, then went to the large tent where Gaul had explained that many of the captives were being kept. Here, he saw Master Gill's hat appear for a moment, then vanish.

sæɾəsfaɪd, pɛɹɪn wɔk bæk aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. əz i dɪd soʊ, hi faʊn sʌmθɪŋ bɑðɝɪŋ hɪm.

Satisfied, Perrin walked back out of the tent. As he did so, he found something bothering him.

ʃʊdn i hæv tʃɹaɪd sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs wən feɪl wɑz kɪdnæpt? hid sɛnt numɝəs skaʊts tə meɪɾən. laɪt hid hæd tə ɹistʃɹeɪn hɪmsɛlf fɹəm mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɔf tə faɪn feɪl ɑn ɪz oʊn.' bʌt hid nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə pleɪs ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.
