Shouldn't he have tried something like this when Faile was kidnapped? He'd sent numerous scouts to Maiden. Light he'd had to restrain himself from marching off to find Faile on his own.' But he'd never tried visiting the place in the wolf dream.

pɝhæps ɪt wʊɾə bɪn jusləs. bʌɾ i hædn kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi, ən ðət tʃɹʌbəl hɪm.

Perhaps it would have been useless. But he hadn't considered the possibility, and that troubled him.

hi fɹoʊz, pæsɪŋ ə kɑɹt pɑɹk bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə waɪtkloʊk tɛns. ðə bæk wɑz oʊpən, ən ə ɡɹɪzəl sɪlvɝ wʊlf leɪ ðɛɹ, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm.

He froze, passing a cart parked beside one of the Whitecloak tents. The back was open, and a grizzled silver wolf lay there, watching him.

"aɪ də lɛt maɪ ətɛnʃən ɡɹoʊ tu nɛɹoʊ, hɑpɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɛn aɪ ɡɛt kənsum baɪ ə ɡoʊl, ɪt kən meɪk mi kɛɹləs. ðət kən bi deɪnʒɝəs. əz ɪn bæɾəl, wən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ædvɝsɛɹi ɪn fɹʌn ə jə kən ɪkspoʊz jə tə ði ɑɹtʃɝ ɑn ðə saɪd."

"I do let my attention grow too narrow, Hopper," Perrin said. "When I get consumed by a goal, it can make me careless. That can be dangerous. As in battle, when concentrating on the adversary in front of you can expose you to the archer on the side."

hɑpɝ kɹækt ɪz maʊθ oʊpən, smaɪlɪŋ æftɝ ðə weɪ ʌv wʊlvz. hi hɑp fɹəm ðə kɑɹt. pɛɹɪn kəd sɛns ʌðɝ wʊlvz nɪɹbaɪ - ði ʌðɝz ə ðə pæk i hæd ɹʌn wɪð bɪfɔɹ. oʊk dænsɝ, spɑɹks ən baʊnləs.

Hopper cracked his mouth open, smiling after the way of wolves. He hopped from the cart. Perrin could sense other wolves nearby - the others of the pack he had run with before. Oak Dancer, Sparks and Boundless.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd tə hɑpɝ. "aɪm ɹɛɾi tə lɝn."

"All right," he said to Hopper. "I'm ready to learn."

hɑpɝ sæt daʊn ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ pɛɹɪn. fɑloʊ, ðə wʊlf sɛnt.

Hopper sat down on his haunches, regarding Perrin. Follow, the wolf sent.

ðən vænɪʃt.

Then vanished.

pɛɹɪn kɝst, lʊkɪŋ əbaʊt. wɛɹ hæd ðə wʊlf ɡɔn? hi muv θɹu ðə kæmp, sɝtʃɪŋ, bʌt kʊdn sɛns hɑpɝ ɛniwɛɹ. hi ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ɪz maɪnd. nʌθɪŋ.

Perrin cursed, looking about. Where had the wolf gone? He moved through the camp, searching, but couldn't sense Hopper anywhere. He reached out with his mind. Nothing.

jʌŋ bʊl. sʌɾənli hɑpɝ wɑz bɪhaɪn hɪm. fɑloʊ. hi vænɪʃt əɡɛn.

Young Bull. Suddenly Hopper was behind him. Follow. He vanished again.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, ðən muvd əbaʊt ðə kæmp ɪn ə flæʃ. wən i dɪdnɝ faɪn ðə wʊlf, hi ʃɪftəd tə ðə fild ʌv ɡɹeɪn wɛɹ hid mɛt hɑpɝ læs taɪm. ðə wʊlf wɑzn ðɛɹ. pɛɹɪn stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə bloʊɪŋ ɡɹeɪn, fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd.

Perrin growled, then moved about the camp in a flash. When he didn'r find the wolf, he shifted to the field of grain where he'd met Hopper last time. The wolf wasn't there. Perrin stood among the blowing grain, frustrated.

hɑpɝ faʊn ɪm ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ. ðə wʊlf smɛl dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. fɑloʊ! hi sɛnt.

Hopper found him a few minutes later. The wolf smelled dissatisfied. Follow! he sent.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "hɑpɝ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

"I don't know how," Perrin said. "Hopper, I don't know where you're going."

ðə wʊlf sæt daʊn. hi sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ə wʊlf pʌp, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ʌðɝz ə ðə pæk. ðə pʌp wɑtʃt ɪz ɛldɝz ən dɪd wʌt ðeɪ dɪd.

The wolf sat down. He sent an image of a wolf pup, joining others of the pack. The pup watched his elders and did what they did.

"aɪm nɑɾ ə wʊlf, hɑpɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ doʊn lɝn ðə weɪ jə du.

"I'm not a wolf, Hopper," Perrin said. "I don't learn the way you do.

jə mʌst ɪkspleɪn tə mi wʌt jə wɑn mi tə du."

You must explain to me what you want me to do."

fɑloʊ hɪɹ. ðə wʊlf sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ʌv, ɑdli, ɛmənz fild. ðən i pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, əpɪɹɪŋ ɑn ə fəmɪljɝ ɡɹin. ə ɡɹup ə bɪldɪŋz laɪn ɪt, wɪtʃ fɛlt ɹɔŋ. ɛmənz fild ʃʊɾə bɪn ə lɪɾəl vɪl- nɑɾ ə taʊn wɪð ə stoʊn wɔl ən ə ɹoʊd ɹʌnɪŋ pæs ðə meɪɝz ɪn, peɪvd wɪð stoʊnz. mʌtʃ hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt taɪm i hæd bɪn əweɪ.

Follow here. The wolf sent an image of, oddly, Emond's Field. Then he perrin followed, appearing on a familiar green. A group of buildings lined it, which felt wrong. Emond's Field should have been a little vil- not a town with a stone wall and a road running past the mayor's inn, paved with stones. Much had changed in the short time he had been away.

"waɪ hæv wi kʌm hɪɹ?" pɛɹɪn æskt. dɪstɝbɪŋli, ðə wʊlfhɛd bænɝ stɪl flu ɑn ðə poʊl əbʌv ðə ɡɹin. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd ɪt. hi nu ɔl tu wɛl haʊ iɡɝli ðə pipəl ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz flu ðə stændɝɾ ʌv "pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz."

"Why have we come here?" Perrin asked. Disturbingly, the wolfhead banner still flew on the pole above the green. It could have been a trick of the wolf dream, but he doubted it. He knew all too well how eagerly the people of the Two Rivers flew the standard of "Perrin Goldeneyes."

mɛn ɑɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

Men are strange, Hopper sent.

pɛɹɪn tɝn tə ði oʊld wʊlf.

Perrin turned to the old wolf.

mɛn θɪŋk stʃɹeɪnʒ θɔts, hɑpɝ sɛd. wi də nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ʌndɝstæn ðɛm. waɪ dʌz ðə stæɡ fli, ðə spɛɹoʊ flaɪ, ðə tʃɹi ɡɹoʊ? ðeɪ du. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl.

Men think strange thoughts, Hopper said. We do not try to understand them. Why does the stag flee, the sparrow fly, the tree grow? They do. That is all.

"vɛɹi wɛl," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Very well," Perrin said.

aɪ kænɑt titʃ ə spɛɹoʊ tə hʌnt, hɑpɝ kəntɪnjud. ən ə spɛɹoʊ dʌz nɑt titʃ ə wʊlf tə flaɪ.

I cannot teach a sparrow to hunt, Hopper continued. And a sparrow does not teach a wolf to fly.

"bʌt hɪɹ, jə kən flaɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"But here, you can fly," Perrin said.

jɛs. ən aɪ wɑz nɑt tɔt. aɪ noʊ. hɑpɝz sɛnt wɑz fʊl ʌv ɪmoʊʃən ən kənfjuʒən. wʊlvz ɔl ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət wʌn ə ðɛɹ kaɪnd nu. hɑpɝ wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd kəz i wɑntəd tə titʃ pɛɹɪn, bʌt wɑzn əkʌstəm tə duɪŋ θɪŋz ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv pipəl.

Yes. And I was not taught. I know. Hopper's scent was full of emotion and confusion. Wolves all remembered everything that one of their kind knew. Hopper was frustrated because he wanted to teach Perrin, but wasn't accustomed to doing things in the way of people.

"pliz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "tʃɹaɪ tə ɪkspleɪn tə mi wʌt jə min. jə ɔlweɪz tɛl mi aɪm hɪɹ 'tu stʃɹɔŋli.' ɪts deɪnʒɝəs, jə seɪ. waɪ?"

"Please," Perrin said. "Try to explain to me what you mean. You always tell me I'm here 'too strongly.' It's dangerous, you say. Why?"

jə slʌmbɝ, hɑpɝ sɛd. ði ʌðɝ ju. jə kænɑt steɪ hɪɹ tu lɔŋ. jə mʌst ɔlweɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət jə ɑɹ ənnætʃɹəl hɪɹ. ðɪs ɪz nɑt jəɹ dɛn.

You slumber, Hopper said. The other you. You cannot stay here too long. You must always remember that you are unnatural here. This is not your den.

hɑpɝ tɝn təwɔɹd ðə haʊsəz ɝaʊn ðɛm. ðɪs ɪz jəɹ dɛn, ðə dɛn ə jəɹ saɪɝ. ðɪs pleɪs.

Hopper turned toward the houses around them. This is your den, the den of your sire. This place.

ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt. ɪɾəl kip jə fɹəm biɪŋ lɔst. ðɪs wɑz haʊ jəɹ kaɪnd wʌns dɪɾ ɪt. jə ʌndɝstænd.

Remember it. It will keep you from being lost. This was how your kind once did it. You understand.

ɪt wɑzn ə kwɛstʃən, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə pli. hɑpɝ wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ tə ɪkspleɪn fɝðɝ.

It wasn't a question, though it was something of a plea. Hopper wasn't certain how to explain further.

aɪ kən tʃɹaɪ," pɛɹɪn θɔt, ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ ðə sɛndɪŋ əz bɛst i kʊd. bʌt hɑpɝ wɑz ɹɔŋ. ðɪs pleɪs wɑzn ɪz hoʊm. pɛɹɪnz hoʊm wɑz wɪð feɪl. hi niɾəd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt, sʌmhaʊ, tə kip hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹɔn ɪndə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim tu stʃɹɔŋli.

I can try," Perrin thought, interpreting the sending as best he could. But Hopper was wrong. This place wasn't his home. Perrin's home was with Faile. He needed to remember that, somehow, to keep himself from getting drawn into the wolf dream too strongly.

aɪ hæv sin jəɹ ʃi ɪn jəɹ maɪnd, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt, kɑkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. ʃiz laɪk ə haɪv ə biz, wɪð swit hʌni ən ʃɑɹp stɪŋz. hɑpɝz ɪmədʒ ə feɪl wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ə vɛɹi kənfjuzɪŋ fimeɪl wʊlf. wʌn u wəd pleɪfəli nɪp əɾ ɪz noʊz wʌn moʊmənt, ðən ɡɹaʊl əɾ ɪm ðə nɛkst, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ əɹ mit.

I have seen your she in your mind, Young Bull, Hopper sent, cocking his head. She is like a hive of bees, with sweet honey and sharp stings. Hopper's image of Faile was that of a very confusing female wolf. One who would playfully nip at his nose one moment, then growl at him the next, refusing to share her meat.

pɛɹɪn smaɪld.

Perrin smiled.

ðə mɛmɹi ɪz pɑɹt, hɑpɝ sɛnt. bʌt ði ʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ɪz ju. jə mʌst steɪ əz jʌŋ bʊl. ə wʊlfs ɹəflɛkʃən ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ, ʃɪmɝɪŋ ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪn-dɪstɪŋkt əz ɹɪpəlz kɹɔst ɪt.

The memory is part, Hopper sent. But the other part is you. You must stay as Young Bull. A wolfs reflection in the water, shimmering and growing in-distinct as ripples crossed it.

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd."

"I don't understand."

ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðɪs pleɪs, hɑpɝ sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ə wʊlf kɑɹvd ə stoʊn ɪz ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ju.

The strength of this place, Hopper sent an image of a wolf carved of stone is the strength of you.

ðə wʊlf θɔt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. stænd. ɹɪmeɪn. bi jə wɪð ðæt, ðə wʊlf stʊɾ ən bækt ʌp, əz ɪf pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə ɹʌn ət pɛɹɪn.

The wolf thought for a moment. Stand. Remain. Be you With that, the wolf stood and backed up, as if preparing to run at Perrin.

kənfjuzd, pɛɹɪn ɪmædʒən hɪmsɛlf əz i wɑz, hoʊldɪŋ ðəɾ ɪmədʒ ɪn ɪz hɛɾ əz stʃɹɔŋli əz i kʊd.

Confused, Perrin imagined himself as he was, holding that image in his head as strongly as he could.

hɑpɝ ɹæn ən dʒʌmpt ət hɪm, slæmɪŋ ɪz bɑɾi ɪndə pɛɹɪn. hid dʌn ðɪs bɪfɔɹ, sʌmhaʊ fɔɹsɪŋ pɛɹɪn aʊɾ ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

Hopper ran and jumped at him, slamming his body into Perrin. He'd done this before, somehow forcing Perrin out of the wolf dream.

ðɪs taɪm, haʊɛvɝ, pɛɹɪn wɑz sɛɾ ən weɪɾɪŋ. ɪnstɪŋktɪvli, pɛɹɪn pʊʃt bæk. ðə wʊlf dʒɹim weɪvɝɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, bʌt ðən ɡɹu fɝm əɡɛn. hɑpɝ ɹɪbaʊndɪɾ ɔf hɪm, ðoʊ ðə hɛvi wʊlf ʃʊɾə nɑk pɛɹɪn tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

This time, however, Perrin was set and waiting. Instinctively, Perrin pushed back. The wolf dream wavered around him, but then grew firm again. Hopper rebounded off him, though the heavy wolf should have knocked Perrin to the ground.

hɑpɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, əz ɪf deɪzd. ɡʊd, hi sɛnt, plizd. ɡʊd. jə lɝn. əɡɛn.

Hopper shook his head, as if dazed. Good, he sent, pleased. Good. You learn. Again.

pɛɹɪn stɛɾid hɪmsɛlf dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə ɡɛt slæm baɪ hɑpɝ ə sɛkən taɪm. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, bʌt hɛl stɛɾi.

Perrin steadied himself just in time to get slammed by Hopper a second time. Perrin growled, but held steady.

hɪɹ, hɑpɝ sɛnt, ɡɪvɪŋ ən ɪmədʒ ə ðə fild ʌv ɡɹeɪn. hɑpɝ vænɪʃt, ən pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd.

Here, Hopper sent, giving an image of the field of grain. Hopper vanished, and Perrin followed.

əz sun əz i əpɪɹd, ðə wʊlf slæmd ɪndə hɪm, maɪn ən bɑɾi.

As soon as he appeared, the wolf slammed into him, mind and body.

pɛɹɪn fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ðɪs taɪm, ɛvɹiθɪŋ weɪvɝɪŋ ən ʃɪmɝɪŋ. hi fɛl hɪmsɛlf biɪŋ pʊʃt əweɪ, fɔɹst aʊɾ ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ən ɪndə hɪz ɔɹɾənɛɹi dʒɹimz.

Perrin fell to the ground this time, everything wavering and shimmering. He felt himself being pushed away, forced out of the wolf dream and into his ordinary dreams.

noʊ/ hi θɔt, hoʊldɪŋ tə ən ɪmədʒ ə hɪmsɛlf nilɪŋ əmʌŋ ðoʊz filz ʌv ɡɹeɪn. hi wɑz ðɛɹ.

No/ he thought, holding to an image of himself kneeling among those fields of grain. He was there.

hi ɪmædʒən ɪt, sɑləɾ ən ɹil. hi smɛl ði oʊts, ðə hjuməɾ ɛɹ, əlaɪv wɪð ðə sɛns ə dɝɾ ən fɔlən livz.

He imagined it, solid and real. He smelled the oats, the humid air, alive with the scents of dirt and fallen leaves.

ðə lændskeɪp koʊəlɛst. hi pæntɪd, nilɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

The landscape coalesced. He panted, kneeling on the ground, but he was still in the wolf dream.

ɡʊd, hɑpɝ sɛnt. jə lɝn kwɪkli.

Good, Hopper sent. You learn quickly.

"ðɛɹz noʊ ʌðɝ ɑpʃən," pɛɹɪn sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ tə hɪz fit.

"There's no other option," Perrin said, climbing to his feet.

ðə læs hʌn kʌmz, hɑpɝ əɡɹid, sɛndɪŋ ən ɪmədʒ ə ðə waɪt-kloʊk kæmp.

The Last Hunt comes, Hopper agreed, sending an image of the White-cloak camp.

pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, bɹeɪsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. noʊ ətæk keɪm. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ ðə wʊlf.

Perrin followed, bracing himself. No attack came. He looked around for the wolf.

sʌmθɪŋ slæmd ɪndə hɪz maɪnd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ moʊʃən, oʊnli ðə mɛntəl ətæk. ɪt wɑzn əz stʃɹɔŋ əz bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. pɛɹɪn bɑɹli mænədʒ tə faɪɾ ɪɾ ɔf.

Something slammed into his mind. There was no motion, only the mental attack. It wasn't as strong as before, but it was unexpected. Perrin barly managed to fight it off.

hɑpɝ fɛl fɹəm ði ɛɹ, lændɪŋ ɡɹeɪsfəli ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɔlweɪz bi ɹɛɾi, ðə wʊlf sɛnt. ɔlweɪz, bʌɾ ɪspɛʃli wən jə muv. ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ə kɛɹ-fʊl wʊlf, tɛstɪŋ ði ɛɹ bɪfɔɹ muvɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ən oʊpən pæstʃɝ.

Hopper fell from the air, landing gracefully on the ground. Always be ready, the wolf sent. Always, but especially when you move. An image of a care-ful wolf, testing the air before moving out into an open pasture.

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd."

"I understand."

bʌt də nɑt kʌm tu stʃɹɔŋli, hɑpɝ tʃaɪɾɪd.

But do not come too strongly, Hopper chided.

ɪmiɾiətli, pɛɹɪn fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ feɪl ən ðə pleɪs wɛɹ i slɛpt. hɪz hoʊm. hi . . . feɪɾəd slaɪtli. hɪz skɪn dɪdnt ɡɹoʊ tʃɹænslusənt, ən ðə wʊlf dʒɹim steɪd ðə seɪm, bʌɾ i fɛl mɔɹ ɪkspoʊzd.

Immediately, Perrin forced himself to remember Faile and the place where he slept. His home. He . . . faded slightly. His skin didn't grow translucent, and the wolf dream stayed the same, but he felt more exposed.

ɡʊd, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾi, bʌt nɛvɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɑn tu stʃɹɔŋ. laɪk kæɹiɪŋ ə pʌp ɪn jəɹ dʒɔz.

Good, Hopper sent. Always ready, but never holding on too strong. Like carrying a pup in your jaws.

"ðæts nɑt gɑnə bi ən izi bæləns," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"That's not going to be an easy balance," Perrin said.

hɑpɝ ɡeɪv ə slaɪtli kənfjuz sɛnt. ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəlt.

Hopper gave a slightly confused scent. Of course it was difficult.

pɛɹɪn smaɪld. "wʌt naʊ?"

Perrin smiled. "What now?"

ɹʌnɪŋ, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ðən mɔɹ pɹæktəs.

Running, Hopper sent. Then more practice.

ðə wʊlf dæʃt əweɪ, zɪpɪŋ ɪn ə blɝ ʌv ɡɹeɪ ən sɪlvɝ ɔf təwɔɹd ðə ɹoʊd. pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd.

The wolf dashed away, zipping in a blur of gray and silver off toward the road. Perrin followed.

hi sɛns dɪtɝməneɪʃən fɹəm hɑpɝ - ə sɛn ðət wɑz ɑdli sɪməlɝ tə ðə weɪ tɑɹn smɛld wən tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz tə faɪt. ðət meɪd pɛɹɪn smaɪl.

He sensed determination from Hopper - a scent that was oddly similar to the way Tarn smelled when training the refugees to fight. That made Perrin smile.

ðeɪ ɹæn daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, ən pɛɹɪn pɹæktəs ðə bæləns ə nɑt biɪŋ ɪn ðə dʒɹim tu stʃɹɔŋli, jɛt biɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə səlɪɾəfaɪ hɪz sɛns ə sɛlf əɾ ɛni moʊmənt. əkeɪʒənəli hɑpɝ wəɾ ətæk hɪm, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɹoʊ hɪm fɹəm ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ðeɪ kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl hɑpɝ - sʌɾənli - stɑpt ɹʌnɪŋ.

They ran down the road, and Perrin practiced the balance of not being in the dream too strongly, yet being ready to solidify his sense of self at any moment. Occasionally Hopper would attack him, trying to throw him from the wolf dream. They continued until Hopper - suddenly - stopped running.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə fju ɛkstʃɹə stɛps, sɝdʒɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ðə wʊlf, bɪfɔɹ stɑpɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ə tʃɹænslusən vaɪəlɪt wɔl ðət kʌt dɝɛkli θɹu ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ɪɾ ɪkstɛndəɾ ʌp ɪndə ðə skaɪ ən dɪstənli tə boʊθ ðə ɹaɪɾ ən ðə lɛft.

Perrin took a few extra steps, surging ahead of the wolf, before stopping. There was something in front of him. A translucent violet wall that cut directly through the roadway. It extended up into the sky and distantly to both the right and the left.

"hɑpɝ?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?"

"Hopper?" Perrin asked. "What is this?"

ɹɔŋɡnəs, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ɪt ʃəd nɑt bi hɪɹ. ðə wʊlf smɛld æŋɡɹi.

Wrongness, Hopper sent. It should not be here. The wolf smelled angry.

pɛɹɪn stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɹeɪzd ə hæn təwɔɹd ðə sɝfəs, bʌt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɪt lʊk laɪk ɡlæs.

Perrin stepped forward and raised a hand toward the surface, but hesitated. It looked like glass.

hid nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. maɪɾ ɪt bi laɪk ðə bʌbəlz ʌv ivəl? hi lʊkt ʌp ət ðə skaɪ.

He'd never seen anything like this in the wolf dream. Might it be like the bubbles of evil? He looked up at the sky.

ðə wɔl flæʃt sʌɾənli ən wɑz ɡɔn. pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt, stʌmbəlɪŋ bæk. hi ɡlænst ət hɑpɝ.

The wall flashed suddenly and was gone. Perrin blinked, stumbling back. He glanced at Hopper.

ðə wʊlf sæɾ ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə wɔl hæd bɪn. kʌm, jʌŋ bʊl, ðə wʊlf faɪnəli sɛnt, stændɪŋ. wɪl pɹæktəs ɪn ənʌðɝ pleɪs.

The wolf sat on his haunches, staring at the Place where the wall had been. Come, Young Bull, the wolf finally sent, standing. We will practice in another place.

hi loʊpt əweɪ. pɛɹɪn lʊk bæk daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. wʌtɛvɝ ðə wɔl hæd bɪn, ɪt hæd lɛf noʊ vɪzəbəl saɪn ʌv ɪts ɛɡzɪstəns. tʃɹʌbəld, pɛɹɪn fɑloʊɾ æftɝ hɑpɝ.

He loped away. Perrin looked back down the road. Whatever the wall had been, it had left no visible sign of its existence. Troubled, Perrin followed after Hopper.

"bɝn mi, wɛɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz ɑɹtʃɝz!" ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi klaɪmd ʌp tə ðə tʌn ə ðə hɪlsaɪd. "aɪ wɑntəɾ əm fɔɹmd ʌp ɑn ðə fɔɹwɝd taʊɝz ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ tə ɹɪliv ðə kɹɔsboʊmən!"

"Burn me, where are those archers!" Rodel Ituralde climbed up to the ton of the hillside. "I wanted them formed up on the forward towers an hour ago to relieve the crossbowmen!"

bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ðə bæɾəl klæŋd ən skɹimd ən ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən θʌmpt ən ɹɔɹd. ə bæn ə tʃɹɑləks hæd sɝdʒd əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, kɹɔsɪŋ ɑn fɔɹd ɹæfs əɹ ə kɹud floʊɾɪŋ bɹɪdʒ fæʃən fɹəm lɔɡ ɹæfs. tʃɹɑləks heɪɾəd kɹɔsɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ɪt tʊk ə lɑt tə ɡɛɾ əm oʊvɝ.

Before him, the battle clanged and screamed and grunted and thumped and roared. A band of Trollocs had surged across the river, crossing on ford rafts or a crude floating bridge fashioned from log rafts. Trollocs hated crossing water. It took a lot to get them over.

wɪtʃ wɑz waɪ ðɪs fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən wɑz soʊ jusfəl. ðə hɪlsaɪd sləp dɝɛkli daʊn tə ði oʊnli fɔɹɾ ə ɹizənəbəl saɪz ɪn liɡz. tə ðə nɔɹθ tʃɹɑləks bɔɪl θɹu ə pæs aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪɾ ən ɹæn ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑɹɪnɛl. wən ðeɪ kəd bi fɔɹst əkɹɔs, ðeɪ feɪs ðə hɪlsaɪd, wɪtʃ hæd bɪn dʌɡ wɪð tʃɹɛntʃɪz, paɪld wɪð bəlwɹks ən sɛt wɪð ɑɹtʃɝ taʊɝz ət ðə tɑp. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi ʌv mɛɹədɑn fɹəm ðə blaɪɾ ɪksɛp baɪ pæsɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɪs hɪl.

Which was why this fortification was so useful. The hillside sloped directly down to the only ford of reasonable size in leagues. To the north Trollocs boiled through a pass out of the Blight and ran right into the River Arinelle. When they could be forced across, they faced the hillside, which had been dug with trenches, piled with bulwarks and set with archer towers at the top. There was no way to reach the city of Maradon from the Blight except by passing over this hill.

ɪt wɑz ən aɪdil pəzɪʃən fəɹ hoʊldɪŋ bæk ə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ fɔɹs, bʌɾ ivən ðə bɛs fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz kəd bi oʊvɝɹʌn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən jəɹ mɛn wɝ taɪɝd fɹəm wiks ə faɪɾɪŋ. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd kɹɔst ən fɔt ðɛɹ weɪ ʌp ðə sloʊp ʌndɝ ə heɪl ʌv æɹoʊz, fɔlɪŋ ɪndə ðə tʃɹɛntʃɪz, hævɪŋ dɪfəkəlti sɝmaʊntɪŋ ðə haɪ bəlwɹks.

It was an ideal position for holding back a much larger force, but even the best fortifications could be overrun, particularly when your men were tired from weeks of fighting. The Trollocs had crossed and fought their way up the slope under a hail of arrows, falling into the trenches, having difficulty surmounting the high bulwarks.

ðə hɪlsaɪd hæɾ ə flæɾ ɛɹiə ət ðə tɑp, wɛɹ ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ɪz kəmæn pəzɪʃən, ɪn ði ʌpɝ kæmp. hi kɔld ɔɹɾɝz əz i lʊk daʊn ɑn ðə woʊvən mæs ə tʃɹɛntʃɪz, bəlwɹks ən taʊɝz. ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ daɪɪŋ tə pɪkmɛn bɪhaɪnd wʌn ə ðə bəlwɹks. ɪɾɝɑldi wɑtʃt əntɪl ðə læs tʃɹɑlɑk -  ən ɪnɔɹməs, ɹæm-feɪs bist - ɹɔɹɾ ən daɪd wɪð θɹi paɪks ɪn ɪts ɡʌt.

The hillside had a flat area at the top, where Ituralde had his command position, in the upper camp. He called orders as he looked down on the woven mass of trenches, bulwarks and towers. The Trollocs were dying to pikemen behind one of the bulwarks. Ituralde watched until the last Trolloc -  an enormous, ram-faced beast - roared and died with three pikes in its gut.

ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ənʌðɝ sɝdʒ wɑz kʌmɪŋ, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ənʌðɝ mæs ə tʃɹɑləks θɹu ðə pæs. ɪnʌf bɑɾiz hæd fɔlən ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz klɔɡd fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ɹʌnɪŋ ɹɛd, ðə kɑɹkəsɪz pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ ə fʊɾɪŋ fəɹ ðoʊz ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪnd.

It looked as if another surge was coming, the Myrddraal driving another mass of Trollocs through the pass. Enough bodies had fallen in the river that it was clogged for the moment, running red, the carcasses providing a footing for those running up behind.

"ɑɹtʃɝz!" ɪɾɝɑldi bɛloʊd. "wɛɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz blʌɾi - "

"Archers!" Ituralde bellowed. "Where are those bloody - "

ə kʌmpəni ʌv ɑɹtʃɝz faɪnəli ɹæn pæst, səm ə ðə ɹɪzɝvz hid hɛl bæk. moʊst ə ðɛm hæd ðə kɑpɝi skɪn ə dəmɑni, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ ə fju stʃɹeɪ tæɹɑbənɝz mɪkst ɪn. ðeɪ kæɹiɾ ə waɪd vɝaɪəɾi ʌv baʊz: nɛɹoʊ dəmɑni lɔŋboʊz, sɝpəntaɪn sɑldəiən ʃɔɹtbaʊz skævənʒd fɹəm ɡɑɹd poʊsts əɹ vɪlədʒəz, ivən ə fju tɔl tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊz.

A company of archers finally ran past, some of the reserves he'd held back. Most of them had the coppery skin of Domani, though there were a few stray Taraboners mixed in. They carried a wide variety of bows: narrow Domani longbows, serpentine Saldaean shortbows scavenged from guard posts or villages, even a few tall Two Rivers longbows.

"lɪdʒɹɪn," ɪɾɝɑldi kɔld. ðə jʌŋ, hɑɹd-aɪɾ ɔfəsɝ hɝiɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɪlsaɪd tə hɪm. lɪdʒɹɪnz bɹaʊn junəfɔɹm wɑz ɹɪŋkəld ən dɝɾi ət ðə niz, nɑt kəz i wɑz əndɪsɪplɪnd, bʌt kəz ðəɹ wɝ tɪmz wən ɪz mɛn niɾəd ɪm mɔɹ ðən ɪz lɔnʒɹi dɪd.

"Lidrin," Ituralde called. The young, hard-eyed officer hurried across the hillside to him. Lidrin's brown uniform was wrinkled and dirty at the knees, not because he was undisciplined, but because there were tims when his men needed him more than his laundry did.

"ɡoʊ wɪð ðoʊz ɑɹtʃɝz tə ðə taʊɝz," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ gɑnə tʃɹaɪ ənʌðɝ pʊʃ. aɪ də nɑt wɑn ənʌðɝ fɪs bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu tə ðə tɑp, hɪɹ mi? ɪf ðeɪ siz əɹ pəzɪʃən ən juz ɪɾ əɡɛnst ʌs, aɪm gɑnə hæv ə ɹɑɾən mɔɹnɪŋ."

"Go with those archers to the towers," Ituralde said. "Those Trollocs are going to try another push. I do not want another fist breaking through to the top, hear me? If they seize our position and use it against us, I'm going to have a rotten morning."

lɪdʒɹɪn dɪdn smaɪl ət ðə kɑmɛnt, əz i wʌns maɪt hæv. hi dɪdn smaɪl mʌtʃ əɾ ɔl ɛnimɔɹ;

Lidrin didn't smile at the comment, as he once might have. He didn't smile much at all anymore;

juʒəwəli oʊnli wən i ɡɑt tə kɪl ə tʃɹɑlɑk. hi səluɾəd, tɝnɪŋ tə dʒɑɡ æftɝ ði ɑɹtʃɝz.

usually only when he got to kill a Trolloc. He saluted, turning to jog after the archers.

ɪɾɝɑldi tɝn lʊk daʊn ðə bæksaɪɾ ə ðə hɪl. ðə loʊɝ kæmp wɑz sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə stip hɪlsaɪd. ðɪs hɪl hæd bɪn ə nætʃɹəl fɔɹmeɪʃən, wʌns, bʌt ðə sɑldəiənz hæd bɪlt ɪɾ ʌp oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz wɪð wʌn lɔŋ sloʊp ɪkstɛndɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ ən ə stipɝ wʌn ɑn ði ɑpəzət saɪd. ɪn ðə loʊɝ kæmp, hɪz tʃɹups kəd slip ən it, ən ðɛɹ səplaɪz kəd bi pɹətɛktəd, ɔl ʃɛltɝd fɹəm ɛnəmi æɹoʊz baɪ ðə stip hɪlsaɪɾ əpɑn wɪtʃ ɪɾɝɑldi naʊ stʊd.

Ituralde turned looked down the backside of the hill. The lower camp was set up there, in the shadow of the steep hillside. This hill had been a natural formation, once, but the Saldaeans had built it up over the years with one long slope extending toward the river and a steeper one on the opposite side. In the lower camp, his troops could sleep and eat, and their supplies could be protected, all sheltered from enemy arrows by the steep hillside upon which Ituralde now stood.

boʊθ ə hɪz kæmps, ʌpɝ ən loʊɝ, wɝ pætʃwɝk θɪŋz. səm ə ðə tɛns hæd bɪn pɝtʃəs fɹəm sɑldəiən vɪlədʒəz, səm wɝ ə dəmɑni meɪk, ən dʌzənz hæd bɪn bɹɔɾ ɪn baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ fɹəm ɔl oʊvɝ ðə lænd. ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm wɝ ɪnɔɹməs kɛɹhinɪn θɪŋz wɪð stʃɹaɪpt pæɾɝnz. ðeɪ kɛp ðə ɹeɪn ɔf ɪz mɛn, ən ðət wɑz ɪnʌf.

Both of his camps, upper and lower, were patchwork things. Some of the tents had been purchased from Saldaean villages, some were of Domani make, and dozens had been brought in by gateway from all over the land. A large number of them were enormous Cairhienin things with striped patterns. They kept the rain off his men, and that was enough.

ðə sɑldəiənz sɝɾənli nu haʊ tə bɪl fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz. ɪf oʊnli ɪɾɝɑldi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə pɝsweɪɾ əm tə liv ðɛɹ haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv mɛɹədɑn ən kʌm hɛlp.

The Saldaeans certainly knew how to build fortifications. If only Ituralde had been able to persuade them to leave their hiding place in the city of Maradon and come help.

"naʊ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "wɛɹ ɪn - "

"Now," Ituralde said, "where in - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz sʌmθɪŋ dɑɹkən ðə skaɪ. hi bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə kɝs ən dʌk əweɪ əz ə ɡɹup ə lɑɹdʒ ɑbʒɛkts ɹeɪn daʊn, ɑɹsɪŋ haɪ tə fɔl ɑn ði ʌpɝ kæmp, ɪlɪsəɾɪŋ haʊlz ə peɪn ən kənfjuʒən. ðoʊz wɝn boʊldɝz: ðeɪ wɝ kɔɹpsəz. ðə hʌlkɪŋ bɑɾiz ə dɛd tʃɹɑləks. ðə ʃæd-oʊzpɔn ɑɹmi hæd faɪnəli sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ tʃɹibətʃəts.

He cut off as something darkened the sky. He barely had time to curse and duck away as a group of large objects rained down, arcing high to fall on the upper camp, eliciting howls of pain and confusion. Those weren't boulders: they were corpses. The hulking bodies of dead Trollocs. The Shad-owspawn army had finally set up their trebuchets.

ə pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪɾɝɑldi wɑz ɪmpɹɛs ðət hid dʒɹɪvən əm tə ɪt. ðə sidʒ ɪkwɪpmən hæɾ əndaʊɾɪdli bɪn bɹɔt tə əsɔl mɛɹədɑn, wɪtʃ wɑz ə lɪɾəl tə ðə saʊθ. sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ðə tʃɹibətʃəts əkɹɔs ðə fɔɹd tə əsɔlt ɪɾɝɑldiz laɪnz ɪnstɛd nɑɾ oʊnli wəd sloʊ ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, bʌt wəɾ ɪkspoʊz ðɛɹ tʃɹibətʃəts tə hɪz kaʊntɝfaɪɝ.

A part of Ituralde was impressed that he'd driven them to it. The siege equipment had undoubtedly been brought to assault Maradon, which was a little to the south. Setting up the trebuchets across the ford to assault Ituralde's lines instead not only would slow the Shadowspawn, but would expose their trebuchets to his counterfire.

hi hædn ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə hɝl kɑɹkəsɪz. hi kɝst əz ðə skaɪ dɑɹkən əɡɛn, mɔɹ bɑɾiz fɔlɪŋ, nɑkɪŋ daʊn tɛns, kɹʌʃɪŋ soʊlʒɝz.

He hadn't expected them to hurl carcasses. He cursed as the sky darkened again, more bodies falling, knocking down tents, crushing soldiers.

"hilɝz!" ɪɾɝɑldi bɛloʊd. "wɛɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz æʃəmən?" hid pʊʃt ði æʃəmən hɑɹd, sɪns ðɪs sidʒ hæd bɪɡʌn. tə ðə bɹɪŋk ʌv ɪɡzɔstʃən. naʊ hi hɛld əm bæk, juzɪŋ əm oʊnli wən tʃɹɑlɑk æz- sɔls ɡɑt tu kloʊs tə ði ʌpɝ kæmp.

"Healers!" Ituralde bellowed. "Where are those Asha'man?" He'd pushed the Asha'man hard, since this siege had begun. To the brink of exhaustion. Now he held them back, using them only when Trolloc as- saults got too close to the upper camp.

"sɝ!" ə jʌŋ mɛsənʒɝ wɪð dɝɾ ʌndɝ ɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz skɹæmbəld ʌp fɹəm fɹʌn laɪnz. hɪz dəmɑni feɪs wɑz æʃən, ən i wɑz stɪl tu jʌŋ tə ɡɹoʊ ə pɹɑpɝ mʌstæʃ. "kæptən fɪnsəs ɹɪpɔɹts ðə ʃædoʊ- spɑn ɑɹmi muvɪŋ tʃɹibətʃəts ɪndə ɹeɪnʒ. ðəɹ ɑɹ sɪkstin baɪ hɪz kaʊnt."

"Sir!" A young messenger with dirt under his fingernails scrambled up from front lines. His Domani face was ashen, and he was still too young to grow a proper mustache. "Captain Finsas reports the Shadow- spawn army moving trebuchets into range. There are sixteen by his count."

"lɛt kæptən fɪnsəs noʊ ðəɾ ɪz blʌɾi taɪmɪŋ kəd bi bɛɾɝ," ɪɾɝɑldi ɡɹaʊld.

"Let Captain Finsas know that his bloody timing could be better," Ituralde growled.

"aɪm sɑɹi, maɪ lɔɹd. ðeɪ ɹoʊld əm daʊn θɹu ðə pæs bɪfɔɹ wi fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. ði ɪnɪʃəl vɑli hɪɾ əɹ wɑtʃpoʊst. lɔɹd fɪnsəs hɪmsɛlf wɑz wundəd."

"I'm sorry, my Lord. They rolled them down through the pass before we figured out what was going on. The initial volley hit our watchpost. Lord Finsas himself was wounded."

ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd; ɹədʒɑbi wɑz ɝaɪvɪŋ tə teɪk kəmæn ə ði ʌpɝ kæmp ən ɔɹɡənaɪz ðə wundəd. bɪloʊ, ə lɑɾ ə bɑɾiz hæd hɪt ðə loʊɝ kæmp, tu. ðə tʃɹibətʃəts kəd ɡɛt ðə haɪɾ ən ɹeɪnʒ tə lɔntʃ oʊvɝ ðə hɪl ən fɔl daʊn ɑn ɪz mɛn ɪn ðɛɹ pɹiviəsli ʃɛltɝɾ ɛɹiə. hiɾ əv tə pʊl ðə loʊɝ kæmp bæk, fɑɹðɝ əkɹɔs ðə pleɪn təwɔɹd mɛɹədɑn, wɪtʃ wəd dɪleɪ ɹɪspɑns taɪmz. blʌɾi æʃəz.

Ituralde nodded; Rajabi was arriving to take command of the upper camp and organize the wounded. Below, a lot of bodies had hit the lower camp, too. The trebuchets could get the height and range to launch over the hill and fall down on his men in their previously sheltered area. He'd have to pull the lower camp back, farther across the plain toward Maradon, which would delay response times. Bloody ashes.

/ nɛvɝ juz tə swɛɹ ðɪs mʌtʃ, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt. ɪt wɑz ðət bɔɪ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɹænd ælθɹ hæd ɡɪvən ɪɾɝɑldi pɹɑməsəz, səm spoʊkən, səm ɪmplaɪd. pɹɑməsəz tə pɹətɛkt ɑɹæd dumən fɹəm ðə sintʃæn. pɹɑməsəz ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi kəd lɪv, ɹæðɝ ðən daɪ tʃɹæp baɪ ðə sintʃæn.

/ never used to swear this much, Ituralde thought. It was that boy, the Dragon Reborn. Rand al'Thor had given Ituralde promises, some spoken, some implied. Promises to protect Arad Doman from the Seanchan. Promises that Ituralde could live, rather than die trapped by the Seanchan.

pɹɑməsəz tə ɡɪv ɪm sʌmθɪŋ tə du, sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, sʌmθɪŋ vaɪɾəl. sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɑsəbəl.

Promises to give him something to do, something important, something vital. Something impossible.

hoʊl bæk ðə ʃædoʊ. faɪɾ əntɪl hɛlp ɝaɪvd.

Hold back the Shadow. Fight until help arrived.

ðə skaɪ dɑɹkən əɡɛn, ən ɪɾɝɑldi dʌkt ɪndə ðə kəmæn pəvɪljən, wɪtʃ hæɾ ə wʊɾən ɹuf əz ə pɹikɔʃən əɡɛnst sidʒ wɛpənz. hid fɪɹd spɹeɪʃɑɾ ə smɔlɝ ɹɑks, nɑt kɑɹkəsɪz.

The sky darkened again, and Ituralde ducked into the command pavilion, which had a wooden roof as a precaution against siege weapons. He'd feared sprayshot of smaller rocks, not carcasses.

ðə mɛn skæɾɝd tə hɛlp pʊl ðə wundəd daʊn tə ðə ɹɛləɾɪv seɪfti ʌv ðə loʊɝ kæmp, ən fɹəm ðəɹ əkɹɔs ðə pleɪn təwɔɹd mɛɹədɑn. ɹədʒɑbi lɛd ði ɛfɝt. ðə lʌmbɝɪŋ mæn hæɾ ə nɛk əz θɪk əz ə tɛn-jɪɹ-ɡɹoʊn æʃ ən ɑɹmz nɪɹli əz waɪd. hi naʊ hɑbəld əz i wɔkt, hɪz lɛf lɛɡ hɝɾ ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ ən æmpjəteɪɾɪd bɪniθ ðə ni. ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd hild ɪm əz bɛst i kʊd, ən i wɔkt ɑn ə pɛɡ. hid ɹəfjuz tə ɹɪtaɪɹ θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz wɪð ðə bædli ɪnʒɝd, ən ɪɾɝɑldi hædn fɔɹs hɪm. jə dɪdn θɹoʊ əweɪ ə ɡʊɾ ɔfəsɝ kəz ʌv wʌn waʊnd.

The men scattered to help pull the wounded down to the relative safety of the lower camp, and from there across the plain toward Maradon. Rajabi led the effort. The lumbering man had a neck as thick as a ten-year-grown ash and arms nearly as wide. He now hobbled as he walked, his left leg hurt in the fighting and amputated beneath the knee. Aes Sedai had Healed him as best he could, and he walked on a peg. He'd refused to retire through gateways with the badly injured, and Ituralde hadn't forced him. You didn't throw away a good officer because of one wound.

ə jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ wɪnst əz ə bloʊɾɪd kɑɹkəs θʌmpt əɡɛns ðə tɑp ə ðə pəvɪljən. ði ɔfəsɝ  - zɛl - dɪdn əv ðə kɑpɝi skɪn ʌv ə dəmɑni, ðoʊ hi wɔɹ ə vɛɹi dəmɑni mʌstæʃ ən ə bjuɾi mɑɹk ɑn ɪz tʃik ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ən æɹoʊ.

A young officer winced as a bloated carcass thumped against the top of the pavilion. The officer  - Zhell - didn't have the coppery skin of a Domani, though he wore a very Domani mustache and a beauty mark on his cheek in the shape of an arrow.

ðeɪ kəd nɑt hoʊld əɡɛns tʃɹɑləks hɪɹ fəɹ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, nɑt wɪð ðə nʌmbɝz ðeɪ wɝ fildɪŋ. ɪɾɝɑldi wəɾ əv tə fɔl bæk, pɔɪn keɪ pɔɪnt, fɑɹðɝ ɪndə sɑldɑiə, fɑɹðɝ təwɔɹɾ ɑɹæd dumən. ɑd, haʊ hi wɑz ɔlweɪz ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪz hoʊmlænd. fɝs fɹəm ðə saʊθ, naʊ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθist.

They could not hold against Trollocs here for much longer, not with the numbers they were fielding. Ituralde would have to fall back, point k point, farther into Saldaea, farther toward Arad Doman. Odd, how he was always retreating toward his homeland. First from the south, now from the northeast.

ɑɹæd dumən wəd bi kɹʌʃt bɪtwin ðə sintʃæn ən ðə tʃɹoʊl-aɪɑks. jud bɛɾɝ kip jəɹ wɝd, bɔɪ.

Arad Doman would be crushed between the Seanchan and the Trol-Iocs. You'd better keep your word, boy.

hi kʊdn ɹitʃɹiɾ ɪndə mɛɹədɑn, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ðə sɑldəiənz ðəɹ hæd meɪɾ ɪt kwaɪt klɪɹ ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝd ɪɾɝɑldi - ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - tə bi ɪnveɪɾɝz. blʌɾi fulz. ət list i hæɾ ə tʃæns tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðoʊz sidʒ ɛnʒənz.

He couldn't retreat into Maradon, unfortunately. The Saldaeans there had made it quite clear they considered Ituralde - and the Dragon Reborn - to be invaders. Bloody fools. At least he had a chance to destroy those siege engines.

ənʌðɝ bɑɾi hɪt ðə tɑp ə ðə kəmæn pəvɪljən, bʌt ðə ɹuf hɛl fɹəm ðə stɪŋk - ænd, ɪn səm keɪsəz, splæʃ - ʌv ðoʊz dɪsis tʃɹɑləks ðeɪd nɑt tʃoʊzən ðə nuli dɛd fəɹ ðɪs əsɔlt.

Another body hit the top of the command pavilion, but the roof held From the stink - and, in some cases, splash - of those deceased Trollocs they'd not chosen the newly dead for this assault.

kɑnfəɾənt ðəɾ ɪz ɔfəsɝz wɝ siɪŋ tə ðɛɹ duɾiz - naʊ wɑz nɑt ðə taɪm tə ɪntɝfɪɹ-ɪɾɝɑldi klæspt ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn hɪm. siɪŋ hɪm, soʊlʒɝz boʊθ ɪnsaɪɾ ən aʊɾ ə ðə pəvɪljən stʊɾ ə lɪɾəl stʃɹeɪɾɝ. ðə bɛst ə plænz læstəɾ oʊnli əntɪl ðə fɝst æɹoʊ hɪt, bʌɾ ə dɪtɝmənd, ənjildɪŋ kəmændɝ kəd bɹɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ tə keɪɑs baɪ ðə weɪ hi hɛl hɪmsɛlf.

Confident that his officers were seeing to their duties - now was not the time to interfere-Ituralde clasped his hands behind him. Seeing him, soldiers both inside and out of the pavilion stood a little straighter. The best of plans lasted only until the first arrow hit, but a determined, unyielding commander could bring order to chaos by the way he held himself.

oʊvɝhɛd, ðə stɔɹm bɔɪld, klaʊdz ə sɪlvɝ ən blæk laɪk ə blækən pɑt hæŋɪŋ əbʌv ə kʊk faɪɝ, bɪts ə stil ʃaɪnɪŋ θɹu ət ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə kɹʌstɪd sʊt. ɪt wɑz ənnætʃɹəl. lɛɾ ɪz mɛn si ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt fɪɹ ɪt, ivən wən ɪt heɪl kɔɹpsəz əpɑn ðɛm.

Overhead, the storm boiled, clouds of silver and black like a blackened pot hanging above a cook fire, bits of steel shining through at the edges of the crusted soot. It was unnatural. Let his men see that he did not fear it, even when it hailed corpses upon them.

wundəd wɝ kæɹiɾ əweɪ, ən mɛn ɪn ðə loʊɝ kæmp bɪɡæn tə bɹeɪk ɪt daʊn, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə muv ɪt fɑɹðɝ bæk. hi kɛpt ɪz ɑɹtʃɝz ən kɹɔsboʊmən faɪɹɪŋ, pɪkmɛn ɹɛɾi əlɔŋ ðə bəlwɹks.

Wounded were carried away, and men in the lower camp began to break it down, preparing to move it farther back. He kept his archers and crossbowmen firing, pikemen ready along the bulwarks.

hi hæɾ ə saɪzəbəl kævəlɹi, bʌt kʊdn juz əm hɪɹ.

He had a sizable cavalry, but couldn't use them here.

ðoʊz tʃɹibətʃəts, ɪf lɛft əloʊn, wəd wɛɹ ɪz mɛn daʊn wɪð boʊldɝz ən spɹeɪʃɑt - bʌɾ ɪɾɝɑldi ɪntɛndəd tə si ðɛm bɝn fɝst, juzɪŋ ən æʃəmən əɹ ə stʃɹaɪk fɔɹs wɪð fleɪmɪŋ æɹoʊz θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ.

Those trebuchets, if left alone, would wear his men down with boulders and sprayshot - but Ituralde intended to see them burned first, using an Asha'man or a strike force with flaming arrows through a gateway.

ɪf oʊnli aɪ kəd ɹitʃɹiɾ ɪndə mɛɹədɑn. bʌt ðə sɑldəiən lɔɹd ðəɹ wʊdn lɛɾ ɪm ɪn; ɪf ɪɾɝɑldi fɛl bæk tə ðə sɪɾi, hid ɡɛt smæʃt əɡɛns ðoʊz wɔlz baɪ ðə tʃɹɑləks.

If only I could retreat into Maradon. But the Saldaean lord there wouldn't let him in; if Ituralde fell back to the city, he'd get smashed against those walls by the Trollocs.

blʌɾi, blʌɾi fulz. wʌt kaɪndə ɪɾiəts dɪnaɪd mɛn ɹɛfjudʒ wən ən ɑɹmi ʌv ʃæɾoʊzpɔn wɑz nɑkɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ ɡeɪts?

Bloody, bloody fools. What kind of idiots denied men refuge when an army of Shadowspawn was knocking on their gates?

"aɪ wɑn dæmədʒ əsɛsməns," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd tə lutɛnənt nɪlz. "pɹipɛɹ ði ɑɹtʃɝz fəɹ ən ətæk ɑn ðoʊz sidʒ ɛnʒənz, ən bɹɪŋ tu ʌv ði æʃəmən u ɑɹ ɑn duɾi. tɛl kæptən kɹiɾɪn tə wɑtʃ ðət tʃɹɑlɑk əsɔlt əkɹɔs ðə fɔɹd. ðəl ɹidʌbəl ðɛɹ ɛfɝts fɑloʊɪŋ ðɪs bɝɑʒ, əz ðəl pɹɪzum əs dɪsɔɹɾɝd."

"I want damage assessments," Ituralde said to Lieutenant Nils. "Prepare the archers for an attack on those siege engines, and bring two of the Asha'man who are on duty. Tell Captain Creedin to watch that Trolloc assault across the ford. They'll redouble their efforts following this barrage, as they'll presume us disordered."

ðə jʌŋ mæn nɑɾəd ən heɪsən ɔf əz ɹədʒɑbi lɪmpt ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz bɹɔd tʃɪn. "ju ɡɛst ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn əbaʊt ðoʊz tʃɹibətʃəts. ðeɪ dɪd sɛɾ əm ʌp tə ətæk ʌs."

The young man nodded and hastened off as Rajabi limped into the pavilion, rubbing his broad chin. "You guessed right again about those trebuchets. They did set them up to attack us."

"aɪ tʃɹaɪ tə ɔlweɪz ɡɛs ɹaɪt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "wɛn aɪ doʊnt, wi luz."

"I try to always guess right," Ituralde said. "When I don't, we lose."

ɹədʒɑbi ɡɹʌntɪd. oʊvɝhɛd, ðət stɔɹm bɔɪld. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ɪɾɝɑldi kəd hɪɹ tʃɹɑləks kɔlɪŋ.

Rajabi grunted. Overhead, that storm boiled. In the distance, Ituralde could hear Trollocs calling.

wɔɹ dʒɹʌmz biɾɪŋ. mɛn ʃaʊɾɪŋ.

War drums beating. Men shouting.

"sʌmθɪŋz ɹɔŋ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

"Something's wrong," Ituralde said.

"ðɪs hoʊl blʌɾi wɔɹ ɪz ɹɔŋ," ɹədʒɑbi sɛd. "wi ʃʊdn bi hɪɹ; ɪt ʃəd bi ðə sɑldəiənz. ðɛɹ hoʊl ɑɹmi, nɑɾ oʊnli ðə fju hɔɹsmən ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɡeɪv ʌs."

"This whole bloody war is wrong," Rajabi said. "We shouldn't be here; it should be the Saldaeans. Their whole army, not only the few horsemen the Lord Dragon gave us."

"mɔɹ ðən ðæt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, skænɪŋ ðə skaɪ. "waɪ kɑɹkəsɪz, ɹədʒɑbi?"

"More than that," Ituralde said, scanning the sky. "Why carcasses, Rajabi?"

"tə dɪmɔɹəlaɪz ʌs."

"To demoralize us."

ɪt wɑz ə nɑt-ənhɝd-ʌv tæktɪk. bʌt ðə fɝs vɑliz? waɪ nɑt juz stoʊnz wən ðeɪd də ðə moʊs dæmədʒ, ən ðən muv tə bɑɾiz wʌns sɝpɹaɪz hæd bɪn ɪkspɛndɪd? ðə tʃɹɑləks hædn ə maɪn fəɹ tæktɪks, bʌt ðə feɪdz . . . ðeɪ kəd bi kɹæfti. hid lɝn ðət fɝsthænd.

It was a not-unheard-of tactic. But the first volleys? Why not use stones when they'd do the most damage, and then move to bodies once surprise had been expended? The Trollocs hadn't a mind for tactics, but the Fades . . . they could be crafty. He'd learned that firsthand.

əz ɪɾɝɑldi stɛɹɾ ət ðə skaɪ, ənʌðɝ mæsɪv vɑli fɛl, əz ɪf spɔn baɪ ðə dɑɹk klaʊdz. laɪt, wɛɹ hæd ðeɪ ɡɑɾən ðət mɛni tʃɹibətʃəts? ɪnʌf tə θɹoʊ hʌnʒɹədz ə dɛd bɑɾiz.

As Ituralde stared at the sky, another massive volley fell, as if spawned by the dark clouds. Light, where had they gotten that many trebuchets? Enough to throw hundreds of dead bodies.

ðəɹ ɑɹ sɪkstin baɪ hɪz kaʊnt, ðə bɔɪ hæd sɛd. nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf. wɝ səm ə ðoʊz kɑɹkəsɪz fɔlɪŋ tu ivənli?

There are sixteen by his count, the boy had said. Not nearly enough. Were some of those carcasses falling too evenly?

ɪt hɪɾ ɪm laɪk ə bɝst ə fɹoʊzən ɹeɪn. ðoʊz klɛvɝ blʌɾi mɑnstɝz!

It hit him like a burst of frozen rain. Those clever bloody monsters!

"ɑɹtʃɝz!" ɪɾɝɑldi skɹimd. "ɑɹtʃɝz, wɑtʃ ðə skaɪz! ðoʊz ɑɹən bɑɾiz!"

"Archers!" Ituralde screamed. "Archers, watch the skies! Those aren't bodies!"

ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. əz i jɛld, ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ ənfɝl ðɛɹ wɪŋz; wɛl oʊvɝ hæf ə ðə "kɑɹkəsɪz"

It was too late. As he yelled, the Draghkar unfurled their wings; well over half of the "carcasses"

ɪn ðɪs vɑli wɝ lɪvɪŋ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, haɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə fɔlɪŋ bɑɾiz. æftɝ ðə fɝs dʒɹæɡkɝ ətæk ɑn ɪz ɑɹmi ə fju deɪz bæk, hid lɛft ɑɹtʃɝz ɑn pɝmənən ɹoʊteɪʃən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə skaɪz deɪ ən naɪt.

in this volley were living Shadowspawn, hiding among the falling bodies. After the first Draghkar attack on his army a few days back, he'd left archers on permanent rotation watching the skies day and night.

bʌt ði ɑɹtʃɝz dɪdn əv ɔɹɾɝz tə faɪɝ ɑn fɔlɪŋ bɑɾiz. ɪɾɝɑldi kəntɪnjud tə bɛloʊ əz i lɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə pəvɪljən ən wɪpt ɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ɪts skæbɝd. ði ʌpɝ kæmp bɪkeɪm keɪɑs əz dʒɹæɡkɝ dʒɹɑpt əmɪd ðə soʊlʒɝz. ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm fɛl ɝaʊn ðə kəmæn pəvəl-aɪən, ðɛɹ tu-lɑɹdʒ blæk aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ, dʒɹɔɪŋ mɛn təwɔɹɾ əm wɪð ðɛɹ swit sɔŋz.

But the archers didn't have orders to fire on falling bodies. Ituralde continued to bellow as he leaped out of the pavilion and whipped his sword from its scabbard. The upper camp became chaos as Draghkar dropped amid the soldiers. A large number of them fell around the command pavil-ion, their too-large black eyes shining, drawing men toward them with their sweet songs.

ɪɾɝɑldi skɹimd əz laʊɾ əz i kʊd, fɪlɪŋ ɪz ɪɹz wɪð ðə saʊn ə hɪz oʊn vɔɪs. wʌn ə ðə bists keɪm fəɹ hɪm, bʌɾ ɪz jɛl pɹɪvɛntɪɾ ɪm fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ ɪts kɹun. ɪt lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd - əz sɝpɹaɪzd əz sʌm- θɪŋ soʊ ɪnhjumən kəd lʊk - əz i stʌmbəl təwɔɹɾ ɪt, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi dʒɹɔn, ðən stʃɹʌk ən ɛkspɝt θɹʌs θɹu ɪts nɛk. dɑɹk blʌd dʒɹɪbəl daʊn əkɹɔs mɪlki waɪt skɪn əz ɪɾɝɑldi jæŋkt ɪz bleɪd fɹi, stɪl skɹimɪŋ.

Ituralde screamed as loud as he could, filling his ears with the sound of his own voice. One of the beasts came for him, but his yell prevented him from hearing its croon. It looked surprised - as surprised as some- thing so inhuman could look - as he stumbled toward it, pretending to be drawn, then struck an expert thrust through its neck. Dark blood dribbled down across milky white skin as Ituralde yanked his blade free, still screaming.

hi sɔ ɹədʒɑbi stʌmbəl ən fɔl tə ðə ɡɹaʊn əz wʌn ə ðə ʃædoʊ-spɑn lɛpt ɑn hɪm.

He saw Rajabi stumble and fall to the ground as one of the Shadow-spawn leaped on him.

ɪɾɝɑldi kʊdnt ɡoʊ tə hɪm - hi wɑz kənfɹʌntəd baɪ ənʌðɝ ə ðə mɑnstɝz hɪmsɛlf. ɪn ə blɛsɪd moʊmənt, hi noʊɾəst bɔlz ə faɪɝ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ daʊn dʒɹæɡkɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ - ði æʃəmən.

Ituralde couldn't go to him - he was confronted by another of the monsters himself. In a blessed moment, he noticed balls of fire striking down Draghkar in the air - the Asha'man.

bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɪn ðə dɪstəns, hi hɝd ðə wɔɹ dʒɹʌmz ɡɹoʊ laʊɾɝ. əz hid pɹɪdɪktɪd, ðə tʃɝnɪŋ fɔɹs ə tʃɹɑləks wəd bi stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə fɔɹd wɪð əz mʌtʃ stʃɹɛŋkθ əz ðeɪ ɛvɝ hæd.

But at the same time, in the distance, he heard the war drums grow louder. As he'd predicted, the churning force of Trollocs would be striking across the ford with as much strength as they ever had.

laɪt, bʌt səmtaɪmz i heɪɾəd biɪŋ ɹaɪt.

Light, but sometimes he hated being right.

jud bɛɾɝ kip jəɹ pɹɑməs tə sɛn mi hɛlp, bɔɪ, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔɾ əz i fɔt ðə sɛkən dʒɹæɡkɝ, hɪz skɹimɪŋ ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɔɹs. laɪt, bʌt jud bɛɾɝ!

You'd better keep your promise to send me help, boy, Ituralde thought as he fought the second Draghkar, his screaming growing hoarse. Light, but you'd better!

feɪl stʃɹoʊd θɹu pɛɹɪnz kæmp, ði ɛɹ ɹɪŋɪŋ wɪð tʃæɾɝɪŋ vɔɪsəz, ɡɹʌns ʌv ɪɡzɝʃən ən kɔlz ə mɛn ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. pɛɹɪn hæd sɛnt wʌn læst ɹɪkwɛs tə ðə waɪtkloʊks fəɹ pɑɹli, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ɹɪplaɪ jɛt.

Faile strode through Perrin's camp, the air ringing with chattering voices, grunts of exertion and calls of men giving orders. Perrin had sent one last request to the Whitecloaks for parley, and there had been no reply yet.

feɪl fɛlt ɹifɹɛʃt. ʃid spɛn ði ɪntaɪɝ naɪt nʌzəld əɡɛns pɛɹɪn ətɑp ðɛɹ hɪl. ʃid bɹɔt plɛnti ʌv bɛɾɪŋ ən blæŋkəts. ɪn səm weɪz, ðə ɡɹæsi hɪltɑp hæd bɪn mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ðən ðɛɹ tɛnt.

Faile felt refreshed. She'd spent the entire night nuzzled against Perrin atop their hill. She'd brought plenty of bedding and blankets. In some ways, the grassy hilltop had been more comfortable than their tent.

ðə skaʊts hæd ɹɪtɝn fɹəm kɛɹhin ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ; ðɛɹ ɹipɔɹt wəd kʌm sun. fəɹ naʊ, feɪl hæd beɪðd ən iɾən.

The scouts had returned from Cairhien this morning; their report would come soon. For now, Faile had bathed and eaten.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt bɹəleɪn.

It was time to do something about Berelain.

ʃi kɹɔs ðə tʃɹæmpəld ɡɹæs təwɔɹd ðə minɝ sɛkʃən ə kæmp, filɪŋ əɹ æŋɡɝ ɹaɪz.

She crossed the trampled grass toward the Mayener section of camp, feeling her anger rise.

bɹəleɪn hæd ɡɔn tu fɑɹ. pɛɹɪn kleɪm ðət ðə ɹumɝz keɪm fɹəm bɹəleɪnz meɪdz, nɑt ðə wʊmən hɝsɛlf, bʌt feɪl sɔ ðə tʃɹuθ. ðə fɝst wɑz ə mæstɝ ə mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ ən kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɹumɝ. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə bɛst weɪz tə ɹul fɹəm ə pəzɪʃən ə ɹɛləɾɪv wiknəs. ðə fɝs dɪd soʊ ɪn min, ən ʃi dɪd ðə seɪm hɪɹ ɪn kæmp, wɛɹ feɪl wɑz ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ pɑɹɾi əz pɛɹɪnz waɪf.

Berelain had gone too far. Perrin claimed that the rumors came from Berelain's maids, not the woman herself, but Faile saw the truth. The First was a master of manipulating and controlling rumor. That was one of the best ways to rule from a position of relative weakness. The First did so in Mayene, and she did the same here in camp, where Faile was the stronger party as Perrin's wife.

ə pɛɹ ʌv wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz stʊɾ ət ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə minɝ sɛkʃən, ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts peɪntəd kɹɪmzən, wɪŋ hɛlməts ʃeɪp laɪk pɑts ən ɪkstɛndɪŋ daʊn ðə bæks ə ðɛɹ nɛks. ðeɪ stʊɾ ʌp tɔlɝ əz feɪl nɪɹd, hoʊldɪŋ lænsɪz ðət wɝ moʊsli ɔɹnəmɛntəl, pɛnənz flæpɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪt stɛnsɪld ɑn ðɛɹ blu lɛŋθs.

A pair of Winged Guards stood at the entrance to the Mayener section, their breastplates painted crimson, winged helmets shaped like pots and extending down the backs of their necks. They stood up taller as Faile neared, holding lances that were mostly ornamental, pennons flapping with the golden hawk in flight stenciled on their blue lengths.

feɪl hæd tə kɹeɪn tə mit ðɛɹ aɪz. "ɛskɔɹt mi tə jəɹ leɪɾi," ʃi ɔɹɾɝd.

Faile had to crane to meet their eyes. "Escort me to your lady," she ordered.

ðə ɡɑɹdz nɑɾəd, wʌn hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn ən weɪvɪŋ fəɹ tu ʌðɝ mɛn fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə kæmp tə teɪk ʌp ðə wɑtʃ. "wi wɝ toʊl tə ɪkspɛk ju," ðə ɡɑɹd toʊl feɪl ɪn ə dip vɔɪs.

The guards nodded, one holding up a gauntleted hand and waving for two other men from inside the camp to take up the watch. "We were told to expect you," the guard told Faile in a deep voice.

feɪl ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "tədeɪ?"

Faile raised an eyebrow. "Today?"

"noʊ. ðə fɝst sɪmpli sɛd ðət ʃəd jə kʌm, jə wɝ tə bi oʊbeɪd."

"No. The First simply said that should you come, you were to be obeyed."

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪm tə bi oʊbeɪd. ðɪs ɪz maɪ hʌzbənz kæmp."

"Of course I'm to be obeyed. This is my husband's camp."

ðə ɡɑɹdz dɪd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju wɪð hɝ, ðoʊ ðeɪ pɹɑbli dɪsəɡɹid.

The guards did not argue with her, though they probably disagreed.

bɹəleɪn hæd bɪn sɛn tə əkʌmpəni pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt bɪn ɡɪvən ɪkspɹɛs kəmæn oʊvɝ əɹ əɹ əɹ tʃɹups.

Berelain had been sent to accompany Perrin, but he had not been given express command over her or her troops.

feɪl fɑloʊd ðə mɛn. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz, baɪ ə mɪɹəkəl, æktʃəli  stɑɹt-ɪŋ tə dʒɹaɪ aʊt. feɪl hæd toʊl pɛɹɪn ðət ʃi wɑzn bɑðɝd baɪ ðə ɹu-mɔɹz bʌt ʃi wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd baɪ bɹəleɪnz boʊlnəs. ðət wʊmən, feɪl θɔt. haʊ dɛɹ ʃi -  noʊ. noʊ, feɪl kʊdn kəntɪnju daʊn ðət pæθ. ə ɡʊd ʃaʊɾɪŋ mætʃ wəd meɪk əɹ fil bɛɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd ɹiɪnfɔɹs ðə ɹumɝz. wʌɾ ɛls wəd pipəl sɝmaɪz ɪf ðeɪ sɔ hɝ stɔk tə ðə fɝsts tɛnt, ðən skɹim ət hɝ? feɪl hæd tə bi kɑm. ðət wəd bi dɪfəkəlt.

Faile followed the men. The ground was, by a miracle, actually start-ing to dry out. Faile had told Perrin that she wasn't bothered by the ru-mors but she was frustrated by Berelain's boldness. That woman, Faile thought. How dare she -  No. No, Faile couldn't continue down that path. A good shouting match would make her feel better, but it would reinforce the rumors. What else would people surmise if they saw her stalk to the First's tent, then scream at her? Faile had to be calm. That would be difficult.

ðə minɝ kæmp wɑz ɝeɪnʒd wɪð laɪnz ə mɛn ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ fɹəm ə sɛntʃɹəl tɛn laɪk spoʊks ɑn ə wil. ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹd dɪdn əv tɛns -  ðoʊz wɝ wɪð mæstɝ ɡɪl - bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə vɛɹi ɔɹɾɝli ɝeɪnʒmənt tə ðə ɡɹupɪŋz. ðeɪ ɔlmoʊst sim tu lɛvəl, ðə foʊldəd blæŋkəts, ðə paɪlz ə lænsɪz, ðə hɔɹs poʊlz ən ðə pɪɹiɑɾɪk faɪɹɛpɪts. bɹəleɪnz sɛntʃɹəl pəvɪljən wɑz lævəndɝ ən mɝun  - sælvədʒ fɹəm meɪɾən. feɪl meɪnteɪn əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ əz ðə tu taʊɝɪŋ ɡɑɹdz lɛɾ əɹ ʌp tə ðə tɛnt. wʌn nɑkt ɑn ðə poʊst aʊtsaɪd fəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə ɛntɝ.

The Mayener camp was arranged with lines of men radiating from a central tent like spokes on a wheel. The Winged Guard didn't have tents -  those were with Master Gill - but there was a very orderly arrangement to the groupings. They almost seemed too level, the folded blankets, the piles of lances, the horse poles and the periodic firepits. Berelain's central pavilion was lavender and maroon  - salvage from Maiden. Faile maintained her composure as the two towering guards led her up to the tent. One knocked on the post outside for permission to enter.

bɹəleɪnz tʃɹæŋkwəl vɔɪs ɹɪspɑndɪd, ən ðə ɡɑɹd pʊʃt bæk ði ɛntʃɹəns flæp fəɹ feɪl. əz ʃi muv tə ɛntɝ, ɹʌslɪŋ ɪnsaɪd meɪɾ əɹ stɛp bæk, ən ənʊɹə keɪm aʊt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nɑɾəd tə feɪl, ði oʊvɝlæpɪŋ bɹeɪdz ɝaʊn əɹ feɪs swɪŋɪŋ. ʃi sim dɪsplizd; ʃi hædn ɹiɡeɪn əɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz feɪvɝ jɛt.

Berelain's tranquil voice responded, and the guard pushed back the entrance flap for Faile. As she moved to enter, rustling inside made her step back, and Annoura came out. The Aes Sedai nodded to Faile, the overlapping braids around her face swinging. She seemed displeased; she hadn't regained her mistress's favor yet.

feɪl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən stɛpt ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən. ɪt wɑz kul ɪnsaɪd. ðə flɔɹ wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð ə mɝun ən ɡɹin ɹʌɡ ʌv ə twɪstɪŋ aɪvi pæɾɝn. ðoʊ ðə pəvɪljən lʊkt ɛmpti wɪθaʊt bɹəleɪnz juʒəwəl tʃɹævəl fɝnɪtʃɝ, ʃi dɪɾ əv ə pɛɹ ə stɝɾi oʊk tʃɛɹz ən ə laɪt teɪbəl fɹəm meɪɾən.

Faile took a deep breath, then stepped into the pavilion. It was cool inside. The floor was covered with a maroon and green rug of a twisting ivy pattern. Though the pavilion looked empty without Berelain's usual travel furniture, she did have a pair of sturdy oak chairs and a light table from Maiden.

ðə fɝst ɹoʊz. "leɪɾi feɪl," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. tədeɪ, ʃi wɔɹ ðə daɪədɛm ə min. ðə θɪn kɹaʊn hæɾ ə sɪmpəl ɡɹænduɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ənɔɹnə-mɛntɪd seɪv fəɹ ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk teɪkɪŋ flaɪɾ əz ɪf lipɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sʌnlaɪt stʃɹimɪŋ ɪn pætʃəz θɹu ðə tɛn silɪŋ. flæps hæd bɪn ɹimuv ðəɹ tə lɛɾ ɪn ðə laɪt. ðə fɝsts dʒɹɛs wɑz ɡoʊld ən ɡɹin, ə vɛɹi sɪmpəl bɛlt əɾ əɹ weɪst, ðə nɛklaɪn plʌnʒɪŋ.

The First rose. "Lady Faile," she said calmly. Today, she wore the diadem of Mayene. The thin crown had a simple grandeur about it, unorna-mented save for the golden hawk taking flight as if leaping toward the sunlight streaming in patches through the tent ceiling. Flaps had been removed there to let in the light. The First's dress was gold and green, a very simple belt at her waist, the neckline plunging.

feɪl sæɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə tʃɛɹz. ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɑz deɪnʒɝəs; ɪt kəd lid tə dɪzæstɝ. bʌɾ ɪt hæd tə bi dʌn.

Faile sat in one of the chairs. This conversation was dangerous; it could lead to disaster. But it had to be done.

"aɪ tʃɹʌs jə ɑɹ wɛl?" bɹəleɪn sɛd. "ðə ɹeɪnz ə ðə læs fju deɪz əv nɑt bɪn oʊvɝli tæksɪŋ?"

"I trust you are well?" Berelain said. "The rains of the last few days have not been overly taxing?"

"ðə ɹeɪnz əv bɪn dʒɹɛdfəl, bɹəleɪn," feɪl sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪm nɑt hɪɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt ðɛm."

"The rains have been dreadful, Berelain," Faile said. "But I'm not here to talk about them."

bɹəleɪn pɝs pɝfək lɪps. laɪt, bʌt ðə wʊmən wɑz bjuɾəfəl! feɪl fɛl daʊnɹaɪt dɪnʒi baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən, hɝ noʊz tu lɑɹdʒ, hɝ bʊzəm tu smɔl. hɝ vɔɪs wɑznt nɪɹli əz məlɑɾɪk əz bɹəleɪnz. waɪ hæd ðə kɹ-ɛɾɝ meɪd pipəl əz pɝfəkt əz bɹəleɪn? wɑz ɪt mɑkɝi ʌv ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm?

Berelain pursed perfect lips. Light, but the woman was beautiful! Faile felt downright dingy by comparison, her nose too large, her bosom too small. Her voice wasn't nearly as melodic as Berelain's. Why had the Cre-ator made people as perfect as Berelain? Was it mockery of the rest of them?

bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪdn lʌv bɹəleɪn. hi lʌv feɪl. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt.

But Perrin didn't love Berelain. He loved Faile. Remember that.

"vɛɹi wɛl," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "aɪ əsum ðɪs dɪskʌʃən wəd kʌm. lemi pɹɑməs jə ðət ðə ɹumɝz ɑɹ æbsəlutli fɔls; nʌθɪŋ ɪnəpɹoʊpɹiɪt hæpən bɪtwin maɪsɛlf ən jəɹ hʌzbənd."

"Very well," Berelain said. "I assumed this discussion would come. Let me promise you that the rumors are absolutely false; nothing inappropriate happened between myself and your husband."

"hi hæz toʊl mi ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi," feɪl sɛd, "æn aɪ tʃɹʌst ɪz wɝɾ oʊvɝ jʊɹz."

"He has told me that already," Faile said, "and I trust his word over yours."

ðɪs meɪd bɹəleɪn fɹaʊn. ʃi wɑz ə mæstɝ ə pəlɪɾəkəl ɪntɝækʃənz, pəzɛsɪŋ ə skɪl ən sʌɾəlti ðət feɪl ɛnvid. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ juθ, bɹəleɪn hæd kɛpt əɹ taɪni sɪɾi-steɪt fɹi fɹəm ðə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ən paʊɝfəl tɛɹ. feɪl kəɾ oʊnli ɡɛs haʊ mʌtʃ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, pəlɪɾəkəl dʌbəl-dilɪŋ ən ʃɪɹ klɛvɝnəs ðət mʌst əv ɹikwaɪɝd.

This made Berelain frown. She was a master of political interactions, possessing a skill and subtlety that Faile envied. Despite her youth, Berelain had kept her tiny city-state free from the much larger and powerful Tear. Faile could only guess how much juggling, political double-dealing and sheer cleverness that must have required.

"soʊ waɪ hæv jə kʌm tə mi?" bɹəleɪn æskt, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn. "ɪf jəɹ hɑɹɾ ɪz əɾ iz, ðən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ pɹɑbləm."

"So why have you come to me?" Berelain asked, sitting down. "If your heart is at ease, then there is no problem."

"wi boʊθ noʊ ðət wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt jə slɛpt wɪð maɪ hʌzbən ɪz nɑɾ ən ɪʃu hɪɹ," feɪl sɛd, ən bɹəleɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd. "ɪɾ ɪzənt wʌt hæpənd, bʌt wʌɾ ɪz pɹəzumd, ðəɾ æŋɡɝz mi."

"We both know that whether or not you slept with my husband is not an issue here," Faile said, and Berelain's eyes widened. "It isn't what happened, but what is presumed, that angers me."

"ɹumɝz kən bi faʊn ɪn ɛni pleɪs wɛɹ pipəl ɑɹ ɡæðɝd," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɛɹ mɛn ɡɑsəp."

"Rumors can be found in any place where people are gathered," Berelain said. "Particularly where men gossip."

"sʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋ, pɝsɪstən ɹumɝz ɑɹ ənlaɪkli tə hæv hæpənd wɪθaʊɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt," feɪl sɛd.

"Such strong, persistent rumors are unlikely to have happened without encouragement," Faile said.

"naʊ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə kæmp - ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz swɔɹn tə mi - əsumz ðət jə bɛɾəd maɪ hʌzbənd waɪl aɪ wɑz əweɪ. ðɪs nɑɾ oʊnli meɪks mi lʊk laɪk ə ful, bʌt kæsts ə ʃædoʊ əpɑn pɛɹɪnz ɑnɝ. hi kænɑt liɾ ɪf pipəl teɪk ɪm fəɹ ðə taɪp ə mæn u wɪl ɹʌn tə ði ɑɹmz ʌv ənʌðɝ wʊmən ðə moʊmən ɪz waɪf ɪz əweɪ."

"Now everyone in the camp - including the refugees sworn to me - assumes that you bedded my husband while I was away. This not only makes me look like a fool, but casts a shadow upon Perrin's honor. He cannot lead if people take him for the type of man who will run to the arms of another woman the moment his wife is away."

"ʌðɝ ɹulɝz əv oʊvɝkʌm sətʃ ɹumɝz," bɹəleɪn sɛd, "æn fəɹ mɛni ʌv ðɛm, ðə ɹumɝz wɝn ənfaʊndɪd. mɑnɑɹkiz sɝvaɪv ɪnfɪdɛlɪɾi."

"Other rulers have overcome such rumors," Berelain said, "and for many of them, the rumors weren't unfounded. Monarchies survive infidelity."

"pɝhæps ɪn ɪljən əɹ tɛɹ," feɪl sɛd, "bʌt sɑldɑiə ɪkspɛks bɛɾɝ ʌv ɪts mɑnɑɹks. əz də ðə pipəl ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. pɛɹɪn ɪz nɑt laɪk ʌðɝ ɹulɝz. ðə weɪ hɪz mɛn lʊk əɾ ɪm ɹɪps ɪm əpɑɹɾ ɪnsaɪd."

"Perhaps in Illian or Tear," Faile said, "but Saldaea expects better of its monarchs. As do the people of the Two Rivers. Perrin is not like other rulers. The way his men look at him rips him apart inside."

"aɪ θɪŋk jə ʌndɝɛstəmeɪt hɪm," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "hi wɪl oʊvɝkʌm ən hɪl lɝn tə juz ɹumɝ fəɹ ɪz ɡeɪn. ðət wɪl meɪk ɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ əz ə mæn ən ə ɹulɝ."

"I think you underestimate him," Berelain said. "He will overcome and he will learn to use rumor for his gain. That will make him stronger as a man and a ruler."

feɪl stʌɾid ðə wʊmən. "ju doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪm əɾ ɔl, də ju?

Faile studied the woman. "You don't understand him at all, do you?

bɹəleɪn ɹiæktəɾ əz ɪf ʃid bɪn slæpt, pʊlɪŋ bæk. ʃi ɑbviəsli dɪdn laɪk ðə blʌntnəs ə ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ðət maɪt ɡɪv feɪl səm slaɪɾ ædvæntɪdʒ.

Berelain reacted as if she'd been slapped, pulling back. She obviously didn't like the bluntness of this conversation. That might give Faile some slight advantage.

"aɪ ʌndɝstæn mɛn, leɪɾi feɪl," bɹəleɪn sɛd koʊldli. "æn jəɹ hʌzbən ɪz noʊ ɪksɛpʃən. sɪns juv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bi kændəd, əl ɹɪtɝn ɪn kaɪnd. jə wɝ klɛvɝ tə teɪk eɪbɑɹə wən jə dɪd, wɛldɪŋ sɑldɑiə tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌt də nɑt θɪŋk ðət hɪl ɹɪmeɪn jʊɹz wɪθaʊt kɑntɛst."

"I understand men, Lady Faile," Berelain said coldly. "And your husband is no exception. Since you have decided to be candid, I will return in kind. You were clever to take Aybara when you did, welding Saldaea to the Dragon Reborn, but do not think that he will remain yours without contest."

feɪl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə meɪk əɹ pleɪ. "pɛɹɪnz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən əz bɪn səvɪɹli dæmədʒ baɪ wʌt juv dʌn, maɪ leɪɾi fɝst. fəɹ maɪ oʊn dɪsɑnɝ, aɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə fɝɡɪv ju. bʌt nɑt fəɹ hɪz."

Faile took a deep breath. It was time to make her play. "Perrin's reputation has been severely damaged by what you have done, my Lady First. For my own dishonor, I might have been able to forgive you. But not for his."

"aɪ doʊn si wʌt kən bi dʌn."

"I don't see what can be done."

"aɪ du," feɪl sɛd. "æn aɪm pɹɪɾi sɝɾən wʌn ʌv əs ɪz gɑnə hæv tə daɪ."

"I do," Faile said. "And I'm pretty certain one of us is going to have to die."

bɹəleɪn ɹɪmeɪn ɪmpæsɪv. "ɪkskjus mi?"

Berelain remained impassive. "Excuse me?"

"ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ɪf ə wʊmən faɪnz ðəɾ ənʌðɝ əz bɪn bɛɾɪŋ əɹ hʌzbənd, ʃiz ɡɪvən ði ɑpʃən ə naɪf kɑmbæt." ðət wɑz tʃɹu, ðoʊ ðə tʃɹədɪʃən wɑz ən oʊld wʌn, ɹɛɹli əbzɝvd ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. "ði oʊnli weɪ tə klɪɹ maɪ neɪm ɪz fəɹ jə ən mi tə faɪt."

"In the Borderlands, if a woman finds that another has been bedding her husband, she is given the option of knife combat." That was true, though the tradition was an old one, rarely observed any longer. "The only way to clear my name is for you and me to fight."

"wʌt wəd ðət pɹuv?"

"What would that prove?"

"ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls, ɪf jə wɝ dɛd, ɪt wəd stɑp ɛniwʌn fɹəm θɪŋkɪŋ ðət jə ɑɹ stɪl slipɪŋ wɪð maɪ hʌzbən bɪhaɪn maɪ bæk."

"If nothing else, if you were dead, it would stop anyone from thinking that you are still sleeping with my husband behind my back."

"ɑɹ jə æktʃəli  θɹɛɾənɪŋ mi ɪn maɪ oʊn tɛnt?"

"Are you actually threatening me in my own tent?"

"ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə θɹɛt," feɪl sɛd, ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ fɝm. laɪt, ʃi hoʊp ðɪs wɛn ðə ɹaɪt weɪ. "ðɪs ɪz ə tʃælənʒ."

"This is not a threat," Faile said, remaining firm. Light, she hoped this went the right way. "This is a challenge."

bɹəleɪn stʌɾid hɝ, aɪz kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ. "aɪ wɪl meɪk ə pʌblɪk steɪtmənt. əl pʌblɪkli tʃæstaɪz maɪ meɪdz fəɹ ðɛɹ ɹumɝz, ən wɪl tɛl ðə kæmp ðət nʌθɪŋ hæpənd."

Berelain studied her, eyes calculating. "I will make a public statement. I will publicly chastise my maids for their rumors, and will tell the camp that nothing happened."

"du jə ɹɪli θɪŋk ðət wəd stɑp ðə ɹumɝz? jə dɪdn əbdʒɛk tə ðɛm bɪfɔɹ maɪ ɹɪtɝn; ðəɾ ɪz sin əz pɹuf. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, naʊ jə wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd tə ækt əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ hæpənd."

"Do you really think that would stop the rumors? You didn't object to them before my return; that is seen as proof. And, of course, now you would be expected to act as if nothing happened."

'ju kæn bi sɪɹiəs əbaʊt ðɪs . . . tʃælənʒ."

'You can't be serious about this . . . challenge."

ɪn ɹɪɡɑɹdz tə maɪ hʌzbənz ɑnɝ, bɹəleɪn, aɪm ɔlweɪz sɪɹiəs." ʃi mɛt ðə wʊmənz aɪz, ən sɔ kənsɝn ðɛɹ. bɹəleɪn dɪdnt wɑnə faɪt hɝ. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, feɪl dɪdnt wɑnə faɪt bɹəleɪn, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən ɪf ʃi kəd wɪn əɹ nɑt. ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə ɡɛt ɹivɛnʒ ɑn ðə fɝs fəɹ ðət taɪm wən bɹəleɪn hæd teɪkən əɹ naɪf fɹəm hɝ.

In regards to my husband's honor, Berelain, I am always serious." She met the woman's eyes, and saw concern there. Berelain didn't want to fight her. And, of course, Faile didn't want to fight Berelain, and not just because she wasn't certain if she could win or not. Though she had always wanted to get revenge on the First for that time when Berelain had taken her knife from her.

"aɪ wɪl meɪk ðə tʃælənʒ fɔɹməli ðɪs ivnɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp," feɪl sɛd, kipɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs ivən. "ju wɪl əv wʌn deɪ tə ɹɪspɑn əɹ liv."

"I will make the challenge formally this evening, before the entire camp," Faile said, keeping her voice even. "You will have one day to respond or leave."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi ə pɑɹɾi tə ðɪs fulɪʃnəs."

"I will not be a party to this foolishness."

"ju ɔlɹɛɾi ɑɹ," feɪl sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt jə sɛɾ ɪn moʊʃən ðə moʊmən jə lɛt ðoʊz ɹumɝz bɪɡɪn."

"You already are," Faile said, rising. "This is what you set in motion the moment you let those rumors begin."

feɪl tɝn tə wɔk fɹəm ðə tɛnt. ʃi hæd tə wɝk hɑɹd tə haɪɾ əɹ nɝvəsnəs. hæd bɹəleɪn sin haʊ hɝ bɹaʊ pɹɪkəld wɪð swɛt? feɪl fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi wɔkt ɑn ðə vɛɹi ɛdʒ ʌv ə sɔɹd.

Faile turned to walk from the tent. She had to work hard to hide her nervousness. Had Berelain seen how her brow prickled with sweat? Faile felt as if she walked on the very edge of a sword.

ʃəd wɝɾ ə ðɪs tʃælənʒ ɡɛt tə pɛɹɪn, hi wəd bi fjʊɹiəs. ʃi hæd tə hoʊp ðət -  "leɪɾi feɪl," bɹəleɪn sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. ðə fɝsts vɔɪs wɑz ɛdʒd wɪð kənsɝn. "ʃʊɹli wi kən kʌm tə ənʌðɝ əkɑmədeɪʃən. də nɑt fɔɹs ðɪs."

Should word of this challenge get to Perrin, he would be furious. She had to hope that -  "Lady Faile," Berelain said from behind. The First's voice was edged with concern. "Surely we can come to another accommodation. Do not force this."

feɪl stɑpt, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ. ʃi tɝn bæk. ðə fɝs lʊk dʒɛnjəwənli wɝid. jɛs, ʃi bɪliv ðət feɪl wɑz blʌdθɝsti ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðɪs tʃælənʒ.

Faile stopped, heart thumping. She turned back. The First looked genuinely worried. Yes, she believed that Faile was bloodthirsty enough to make this challenge.

"aɪ wɑn jə aʊɾ ə pɛɹɪnz laɪf, bɹəleɪn," feɪl sɛd. "aɪ wɪl əv ðæt, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ."

"I want you out of Perrin's life, Berelain," Faile said. "I will have that, one way or another."

"ju wɪʃ mi tə liv?" bɹəleɪn æskt. "ðə tæsks ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɡeɪv mi ɑɹ fɪnɪʃt. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kəd teɪk maɪ mɛn ən mɑɹtʃ ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən."

"You wish me to leave?" Berelain asked. "The tasks the Lord Dragon gave me are finished. I suppose I could take my men and march another direction."

noʊ, feɪl dɪdnt wɑn əɹ tə ɡoʊ. ðə dɪsəpɪɹəns ə hɝ tʃɹups wəd bi ə bloʊ, ɪn ðə feɪs ə ðət lumɪŋ waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi. ən pɛɹɪn wəɾ əv niɾ ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛn, feɪl səspɛktəd.

No, Faile didn't want her to go. The disappearance of her troops would be a blow, in the face of that looming Whitecloak army. And Perrin would have need of the Winged Guard again, Faile suspected.

"noʊ," feɪl sɛd. "livɪŋ wɪl də nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹumɝz, bɹəleɪn."

"No," Faile said. "Leaving will do nothing for the rumors, Berelain."

"ɪt wɪl də əz mʌtʃ əz kɪlɪŋ mi wʊd," ðə wʊmən sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ɪf wi faɪt, ən jə sʌmhaʊ mænədʒ tə kɪl mi, ɔl ðət wəd bi sɛɾ ɪz ðət jə dɪskʌvɝd jəɹ hʌzbənz ɪnfɪdɛlɪɾi ən bɪkeɪm ɛnɹeɪdʒd. aɪ feɪl tə si haʊ ðət wəd hɛlp jəɹ pəzɪʃən. ɪt wəɾ oʊnli ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə ɹumɝz."

"It will do as much as killing me would," the woman said dryly. "If we fight, and you somehow managed to kill me, all that would be said is that you discovered your husband's infidelity and became enraged. I fail to see how that would help your position. It would only encourage the rumors."

"ju si maɪ pɹɑbləm, ðɛn," feɪl sɛd, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɛksæspɝeɪʃən ʃoʊ θɹu. "ðɛɹ simz tə bi noʊ weɪ tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðiz ɹumɝz."

"You see my problem, then," Faile said, letting her exasperation show through. "There seems to be no way to be rid of these rumors."

bɹəleɪn stʌɾid hɝ. ðə wʊmən hæd wʌns pɹɑməst ʃi wəd teɪk pɛɹɪn. hæɾ ɔl bʌt vaʊɾ ɪt.

Berelain studied her. The woman had once promised she would take Perrin. Had all but vowed it.

ʃi sim tə hæv bækt ɔf ɑn ðæt, ɪn pɑɹt, ɹisənli. ən əɹ aɪz ʃoʊd hɪns ʌv wɝi.

She seemed to have backed off on that, in part, recently. And her eyes showed hints of worry.

ʃi ɹiəlaɪzɪz ðət ʃi lɛt ðɪs ɡoʊ tu fɑɹ, feɪl θɔt, ʌndɝstændɪŋ. əɹ kɔɹs. bɹəleɪn hædn ɪkspɛktəd feɪl tə ɹɪtɝn fɹəm meɪɾən. ðət wɑz waɪ ʃid meɪd sətʃ ə boʊl muv.

She realizes that she let this go too far, Faile thought, understanding. Or course. Berelain hadn't expected Faile to return from Maiden. That was why she'd made such a bold move.

naʊ ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃiɾ oʊvɝɪkstɛndəd hɝsɛlf. ən ʃi lədʒɪɾəmətli θɔt feɪl ənhɪnʒd ɪnʌf tə duəl əɹ ɪn pʌblɪk.

Now she realized she'd overextended herself. And she legitimately thought Faile unhinged enough to duel her in public.

"aɪ nɛvɝ wɑntəd ðɪs, bɹəleɪn," feɪl sɛd, wɔkɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə tɛnt. "ænd niðɝ dɪd pɛɹɪn.

"I never wanted this, Berelain," Faile said, walking back into the tent. "And neither did Perrin.

jəɹ ətɛnʃənz ɑɹ ən ənɔɪəns tə əs boʊθ."

Your attentions are an annoyance to us both."

"jɔɹ hʌzbən dɪd lɪɾəl tə dɪsweɪd mi," bɹəleɪn sɛd, ɑɹmz foʊldəd. "dʊɹɪŋ jəɹ æbsəns, ðəɹ wɝ pɔɪns wɛɹ i dɝɛkli ɛnkɝɪdʒ mi."

"Your husband did little to dissuade me," Berelain said, arms folded. "During your absence, there were points where he directly encouraged me."

"ju ʌndɝstæn ɪm soʊ lɪɾəl, bɹəleɪn." ɪt wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ haʊ ðə mæn kəd bi soʊ blaɪnd waɪl biɪŋ soʊ klɛvɝ ɪn ʌðɝ weɪz.

"You understand him so little, Berelain." It was amazing how the man could be so blind while being so clever in other ways.

"soʊ jə kleɪm," bɹəleɪn sɛd.

"So you claim," Berelain said.

"ju hæv tu tʃɔɪsəz ɹaɪt naʊ, bɹəleɪn," feɪl sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə hɝ. "ju kən faɪt mi, ən wʌn ʌv əs wɪl daɪ. jəɹ ɹaɪt, ðət wʊdnt n ðə ɹumɝz. bʌɾ ɪt wəɾ ɛn jəɹ tʃænsəz ət pɛɹɪn. iðɝ jud bi dɛɾ əɹ jud bi ðə wʊmən u kɪld ɪz waɪf.

"You have two choices right now, Berelain," Faile said, stepping up to her. "You can fight me, and one of us will die. You're right, that wouldn't nd the rumors. But it would end your chances at Perrin. Either you'd be dead or you'd be the woman who killed his wife.

"jɔɹ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs," feɪl sɛd, miɾɪŋ bɹəleɪnz aɪz, "ɪz tə kʌm ʌp wɪð ə weɪ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðiz ɹumɝz wʌns ən fəɹ ɔl. jə kɑz ðɪs mɛs.

"Your other choice," Faile said, meeting Berelain's eyes, "is to come up with a way to destroy these rumors once and for all. You caused this mess.

jəl fɪks ɪt."

You will fix it."

ən ðəɹ wɑz əɹ ɡæmbəl. feɪl kʊdn θɪŋk ʌv ə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən, bʌt bɹəleɪn wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ əkɑmplɪʃt ɪn ðɪs ɹəɡɑɹd ðən ʃi wɑz. soʊ feɪl keɪm, pɹipɛɹd tə mənɪpjəleɪt bɹəleɪn ɪndə θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə də sʌmθɪŋ ənɹiznəbəl. ðən lɛt ðə wʊmənz ɪmpɹɛsɪv pəlɪɾəkəl əkjumən ətæk ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən.

And there was her gamble. Faile couldn't think of a way out of the situation, but Berelain was much more accomplished in this regard than she was. So Faile came, prepared to manipulate Berelain into thinking she was ready to do something unreasonable. Then let the woman's impressive political acumen attack the situation.

wəɾ ɪt wɝk?

Would it work?

feɪl mɛt bɹəleɪnz aɪz, ən əlaʊd hɝsɛlf tə fil əɹ æŋɡɝ. hɝ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ət wʌt hæd hæpənd. ʃi wɑz biɪŋ biɾən, fɹoʊzən ən hjumɪlieɪɾɪd baɪ ðɛɹ kɑmən ɛnəmi. ən dʊɹɪŋ ðæt, bɹəleɪn hæd ðə ɡɔl tə də sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs?

Faile met Berelain's eyes, and allowed herself to feel her anger. Her outrage at what had happened. She was being beaten, frozen and humiliated by their common enemy. And during that, Berelain had the gall to do something like this?

ʃi hɛl ðə fɝsts aɪz. noʊ, feɪl dɪd nɑɾ əv əz mʌtʃ pəlɪɾəkəl ɪkspɪɹiəns əz bɹəleɪn. bʌt ʃi hæd sʌmθɪŋ ðə wʊmən dɪdnt. ʃi lʌv pɛɹɪn. dipli, tʃɹuli. ʃi wəd də ɛniθɪŋ tə kip ɪm fɹəm biɪŋ hɝt.

She held the First's eyes. No, Faile did not have as much political experience as Berelain. But she had something the woman didn't. She loved Perrin. Deeply, truly. She would do anything to keep him from being hurt.

ðə fɝst stʌɾid hɝ. "vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛd. "soʊ bi ɪt. bi pɹaʊɾ ə jɝsɛlf, feɪl. ɪts . . . ɹɛɹ ðəɾ aɪ teɪk maɪsɛlf ɔf ə pɹaɪz aɪ hæv lɔŋ dɪzaɪɝd."

The First studied her. "Very well," she said. "So be it. Be proud of yourself, Faile. It is . . . rare that I take myself off a prize I have long desired."

"ju hævən sɛd haʊ wi kəd ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə ɹumɝz." "ðɛɹ meɪ bi ə mɛθəd," bɹəleɪn sɛd.

"You haven't said how we could get rid of the rumors." "There may be a method," Berelain said.

"bʌɾ ɪɾəl bi dɪsteɪsfəl." feɪl ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

"But it will be distasteful." Faile raised an eyebrow.

wɪl nid tə bi sin əz fɹɛnz," bɹəleɪn ɪkspleɪnd. "faɪɾɪŋ, biɪŋ əɾ ɑdz, ðɪs wɪl fjuəl ðə ɹumɝz. bʌɾ ɪf wəɹ sin spɛndɪŋ taɪm wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ, ɪɾəl dɪsɑɹm ðɛm. ðæt, mɪkst wɪð ə fɔɹməl ɹɪnʌnsieɪʃən ɑn maɪ pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹumɝz, wɪl laɪkli bi ɪnʌf."

We will need to be seen as friends," Berelain explained. "Fighting, being at odds, this will fuel the rumors. But if we are seen spending time with one another, it will disarm them. That, mixed with a formal renunciation on my part of the rumors, will likely be enough."

feɪl sæt daʊn ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn juzɪŋ ɝliɝ. fɹɛnz? ʃi dɪtɛstɪd ðɪs wʊmən.

Faile sat down in the chair she had been using earlier. Friends? She detested this woman.

ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi ə bəlivəbəl ækt," bɹəleɪn sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ən wɔkɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ðə sɝvɪŋ stæn ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə tɛnt. ʃi pɔɹd hɝsɛlf səm tʃɪld waɪn. "oʊnli ðət wəd wɝk."

It would have to be a believable act," Berelain said, rising and walking over to the serving stand at the corner of the tent. She poured herself some chilled wine. "Only that would work."

"jul faɪn ənʌðɝ mæn, əz wɛl," feɪl sɛd. "sʌmwʌn jə kən ɡɪv jəɹ ətɛnʃənz tə, fəɹ ə taɪm ət list. tə pɹuv ðət jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪntɪɹ ɪn pɛɹɪn."

"You'll find another man, as well," Faile said. "Someone you can give your attentions to, for a time at least. To prove that you are not intere in Perrin."

bɹəleɪn ɹeɪz ðə kʌp. "jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ səspɛk ðət wəd hɛlp tu.

Berelain raised the cup. "Yes," she said. "I suspect that would help too.

kən jə pʊɾ ɑn sətʃ ən ækt, feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə?"

Can you put on such an act, Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara?"

jə bɪlivd aɪ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə kɪl jə oʊvɝ ðɪs, dɪdn ju, feɪl θɔt, "aɪ pɹɑməs ɪt."

You believed I was ready to kill you over this, didn't you, Faile thought, "I promise it."

bɹəleɪn pɔzd, waɪnkʌp hæfweɪ tə hɝ lɪps. ðən ʃi smaɪld, ən dʒɹæŋk. "wi ʃæl si, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ðə kʌp, "wʌt kʌmz ə ðɪs"

Berelain paused, winecup halfway to her lips. Then she smiled, and drank. "We shall see, then," she said, lowering the cup, "what comes of this"


tʃæptɝ naɪntin


CHAPTER 19

tɔk ə dʒɹæɡənz


Talk of Dragons

mæt tʌɡd ɑn ə stɝɾi bɹaʊn koʊt. ðə bʌɾənz wɝ bɹæs, bʌɾ ʌðɝ ðən ðæt, ɪt wɑz fɹi ʌv ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən. meɪɾ ʌv ə θɪk wʊl, ɪt hæɾ ə fju hoʊlz fɹəm æɹoʊz ðət ɹɪli ʃʊɾə kɪl hɪm. wʌn ə ðə hoʊlz hæɾ ə blʌdsteɪn ɝaʊn ɪt, bʌt ðət hæd moʊsli bɪn wɑʃt aʊt. ɪt wɑz ə naɪs koʊt. hi wʊɾə peɪd ɡʊd kɔɪn fəɹ ə koʊt laɪk ðɪs wʌn, wən i lɪv bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

Mat tugged on a sturdy brown coat. The buttons were brass, but other than that, it was free of ornamentation. Made of a thick wool, it had a few holes from arrows that really should have killed him. One of the holes had a bloodstain around it, but that had mostly been washed out. It was a nice coat. He would have paid good coin for a coat like this one, when he lived back in the Two Rivers.

hi ɹʌbd ɪz feɪs, lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ ə hɪz nu tɛnt. hi hæd ʃeɪvd ɔf ðət blʌɾi bɪɹd, faɪnəli. haʊ dɪd pɛɹɪn mænədʒ ðət blʌɾi ɪtʃɪŋ? ðə mæn mʌst əv sændpeɪpɝ fəɹ skɪn. wɛl, mæt wəd faɪn ənʌðɝ weɪ tə dɪsɡaɪz hɪmsɛlf, wən niɾəd.

He rubbed his face, looking in the mirror of his new tent. He had shaved off that bloody beard, finally. How did Perrin manage that bloody itching? The man must have sandpaper for skin. Well, Mat would find another way to disguise himself, when needed.

hi hæd nɪk hɪmsɛlf ə fju taɪmz waɪl ʃeɪvɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf i hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪmsɛlf. hi dɪd nɑt niɾ ə mænsɝvən tə də wʌɾ i kəd mænədʒ ɑn ɪz oʊn. nɑɾɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, hi pʊld ɑn ɪz hæɾ ən ɡɹæbd ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə tɛnt; ðə ɹeɪvənz ɑn ðə bleɪd sim tə pɝtʃ ɪksaɪɾədli ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən ə bæɾəlz tə kʌm. "blʌɾi ɹaɪt jə du," mæt sɛd, ɹɛstɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz i wɔkt aʊɾ əɹ ðə tɛnt. hi ɡɹæbd ɪz pæk ən slʌŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʌðɝ ʃoʊldɝ, stɑɹɾɪŋ tənaɪt, hi wəd bi spɛndɪŋ naɪts ɪn ðə sɪɾi.

He had nicked himself a few times while shaving. But it was not as if he had forgotten how to take care of himself. He did not need a manservant to do what he could manage on his own. Nodding to himself, he pulled on his hat and grabbed his ashandarei from the corner of the tent; the ravens on the blade seemed to perch excitedly in anticipation of battles to come. "Bloody right you do," Mat said, resting the ashandarei on his shoulder as he walked out or the tent. He grabbed his pack and slung it over his other shoulder, Starting tonight, he would be spending nights in the city.

hi stʃɹoʊd θɹu kæmp, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə ɡɹup ə pæsɪŋ ɹɛdʒɹmz. hi hæd dʌbəl ðə wɑtʃ. hi wɑz wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðə ɡoʊləm, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ əbaʊt ðə mɛni mɪlətɛɹi kæmps ɪn ði ɛɹiə. hæf wɝ mɝsənɛɹiz, hæf wɝ ðə ɹɪteɪnɝz ə ðɪs maɪnɝ lɔɹɾ əɹ ðæt, kʌmɪŋ tə peɪ ɹɪspɛks tə ðə kwin səspɪʃəsli ɝaɪvɪŋ æftɝ ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɑz dʌn.

He strode through camp, nodding to a group of passing Redarms. He had doubled the watch. He was worried about the gholam, but also about the many military camps in the area. Half were mercenaries, half were the retainers of this minor lord or that, coming to pay respects to the Queen suspiciously arriving after the righting was done.

noʊ daʊɾ itʃ ən ɛvɹi wʌn wɑz pɹəfɛsɪŋ ɪz hɑɹtfɛlt əlidʒəns tə ɪleɪn, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz mɛn səpɔɹɾəd əɹ ɔl əlɔŋ. ðɛɹ wɝdz pɹɑb-eɪbli fɛl ə lɪɾəl flæt, sɪns mæt hæɾ ɪɾ ɑn ɡʊɾ əθɔɹəɾi fɹəm θɹi sɛpɹət dʒɹʌŋks ɪn tævɝnz ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd juz tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪkstɛnsɪvli ɪn ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ əɹ dɪfɛns. ɪt wɑz iziɝ tə feɪn ə dɪleɪɾ ɝaɪvəl wən jə wɝ ɹɪspɑndɪŋ tə ə ɹɪɾən mɛsədʒ.

No doubt each and every one was professing his heartfelt allegiance to Elayne, explaining that his men supported her all along. Their words prob-ably fell a little flat, since Mat had it on good authority from three separate drunks in taverns that Elayne had used Traveling extensively in recruiting her defense. It was easier to feign a delayed arrival when you were responding to a written message.

"mæt! mæt!"

"Mat! Mat!"

mæt stɑpt ɑn ðə pæθweɪ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz tɛn əz oʊlvɝ keɪm ɹeɪsɪŋ ʌp ðə bɔɪ hæd teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ ə ɹɛd bæn ɝaʊn ɪz ɑɹm, mʌtʃ əz ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz dɪd, bʌɾ i stɪl wɔɹ ɪz bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz ən koʊt. hi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ɪz ɹoʊld-ʌp klɔθ fəɹ sneɪks ən fɑksəz ʌndɝ wʌn ɑɹm ən ə pæk slʌŋ oʊvɝ ði ʌðɝ.

Mat stopped on the pathway outside his tent as Olver came racing up The boy had taken to wearing a red band around his arm, much as the Redarms did, but he still wore his brown trousers and coat. He was carrying his rolled-up cloth for Snakes and Foxes under one arm and a pack slung over the other.

sɛɾəl stʊɾ ɪn ðə nɪɹ dɪstəns, əlɔŋ wɪð lʌsɪn ən ɛɾɝ, tu ɹɛdʒɹmz ðət mæt hæɾ əsaɪn tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ əɹ ən ðə bɔɪ. ðeɪd bi dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə sɪɾi sun.

Setalle stood in the near distance, along with Lussin and Edder, two Redarms that Mat had assigned to watch over her and the boy. They'd be departing for the city soon.

"mæt," oʊlvɝ sɛd, pæntɪŋ. "jɔɹ livɪŋ?"

"Mat," Olver said, panting. "You're leaving?"

"aɪ doʊn əv taɪm tə pleɪ wɪð jə naʊ, oʊlvɝ," mæt sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ tə ðə kɹʊk ə hɪz ɑɹm. "aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ mit wɪð ə kwin."

"I don't have time to play with you now, Olver," Mat said, lowering his ashandarei to the crook of his arm. "I have to go meet with a Queen."

"aɪ noʊ," oʊlvɝ sɛd. "aɪ fɪɡjɝd ðət sɪns wɝ boʊθ ɡoʊɪŋ tə taʊn, wi kəd ɹaɪd təɡɛðɝ ən plæn. aɪ hæv səm aɪdiəz əbaʊt haʊ tə dɪfit ðə sneɪks ən ðə fɑksəz! wɝ gɑnə ʃoʊ ðɛm, mæt.

"I know," Olver said. "I figured that since we're both going to town, we could ride together and plan. I have some ideas about how to defeat the snakes and the foxes! We're going to show them, Mat.

bɝn mi, bʌt wi blʌɾi wɪl!"

Burn me, but we bloody will!"

"hu tɔt jə ðət læŋɡwədʒ?"

"Who taught you that language?"

"mæt," hi sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt! wɪv tə plæn! wi hævən tɔkt əbaʊt wʌt wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du."

"Mat," he said. "This is important! We have to plan! We haven't talked about what we're going to do."

saɪlənli, mæt kɝs hɪmsɛlf fəɹ dɪskʌsɪŋ ðə kwɛs tə ɹɛskju mwɑ-ɹeɪn wɛɹ oʊlvɝ kəd hɪɹ.

Silently, Mat cursed himself for discussing the quest to rescue Moi-raine where Olver could hear.

ðə bɔɪ wɑz nɑt gɑnə teɪk ɪt wɛl wən i wɑz lɛf bɪhaɪnd.

The boy was not going to take it well when he was left behind.

"aɪ nid tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌɾ aɪm gɑnə seɪ tə ðə kwin," mæt sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "bʌɾ aɪ ɡɛs jəɹ ɹaɪt, plænɪŋ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. waɪ doʊn jə ɡoʊ tɛl noʊl əbaʊt jəɹ aɪdiəz?"

"I need to think about what I'm going to say to the Queen," Mat said, rubbing his chin. "But I guess you're right, planning is important. Why don't you go tell Noal about your ideas?"

"aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪd," oʊlvɝ sɛd. "æn θɔɹn tu. ən tælmɑnz."

"I already did," Olver said. "And Thorn too. And Talmanes."

tælmɑnz? hi wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð əm ɪndə ðə taʊɝ! laɪt, haʊ mʌtʃ hæɾ oʊlvɝ bɪn spɹɛɾɪŋ ðə nuz ɝaʊnd?

Talmanes? He was not going with them into the Tower! Light, how much had Olver been spreading the news around?

"oʊlvɝ," mæt sɛd, skwɑɾɪŋ daʊn tə bi ɑn aɪ lɛvəl wɪð ðə bɔɪ, "ju nid tə kip kwaɪəɾɝ. wi doʊnt wɑn tu mɛni pipəl noʊɪŋ wʌt wɝ duɪŋ."

"Olver," Mat said, squatting down to be on eye level with the boy, "you need to keep quieter. We don't want too many people knowing what we're doing."

"aɪ dɪdn tɛl noʊbɑdi wi doʊn tʃɹʌst, mæt," oʊlvɝ sɛd. "doʊnt wɝi, moʊst wɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz."

"I didn't tell nobody we don't trust, Mat," Olver said. "Don't worry, Most were Redarms."

ɡɹeɪt, mæt θɔt. wʌt wəd ðə soʊlʒɝz θɪŋk ə ðɛɹ kəmændɝ plænɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɔf ən faɪɾ ə bʌntʃ ə kɹitʃɝz fɹəm tʃɪlʒɹənz stɔɹiz? hoʊpfəli ðeɪ wəd si oʊlvɝz kɑmɛns əz ðə fænsiz ʌv ə jʌŋ bɔɪ.

Great, Mat thought. What would the soldiers think of their commander planning to go off and fight a bunch of creatures from children's stories? Hopefully they would see Olver's comments as the fancies of a young boy.

"dʒʌs bi kɛɹfəl," mæt sɛd. "aɪl kʌm stɑp baɪ jəɹ ɪn təmɑɹoʊ, ən kən pleɪ ə ɡeɪm ðən ən tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"Just be careful," Mat said. "I'll come stop by your inn tomorrow, and can play a game then and talk about it. All right?"

oʊlvɝ nɑɾəd. "ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt. bʌt . . . blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" hi tɝn ən wɔkt əweɪ.

Olver nodded. "All right, Mat. But . . . blood and bloody ashes!" He turned and walked away.

"æn stɑp swɛɹɪŋ!" mæt kɔld æftɝ hɪm, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. blʌɾi soʊlʒɝz wəɾ əv oʊlvɝ kɝʌptɪd baɪ ðə taɪm i wɑz twɛlv.

"And stop swearing!" Mat called after him, then shook his head. Bloody soldiers would have Olver corrupted by the time he was twelve.

mæt kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn ɪz weɪ, linɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əɡɛn. hi faʊn θɔɹn ən tælmɑnz maʊntəɾ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kæmp əlɔŋ wɪð ə fɔɹs ə fɪfti ɹɛdʒɹmz. θɔɹn wɔɹ ən ɪkstʃɹævəɡənt waɪn-ɹɛd koʊɾ ən tʃɹaʊzɝz, ɡoʊld wɝk ət ði ɑɹmz, wɪð ə ʃɝt bɛɹɪŋ waɪt leɪs ət ðə kʌfs ən ə sɪlkən kɹævæt taɪɾ ət ðə nɛk. ðə bʌɾənz wɝ ʌv ɡlimɪŋ ɡoʊld. hɪz mʌstæʃɪz hæd bɪn tʃɹɪmd ən nitli koʊmd. ði ɪntaɪɝ aʊtfɪt wɑz nu, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə blæk kloʊk, ɪts ɪnɝ laɪnɪŋ ʌv ɡoʊld.

Mat continued on his way, leaning his spear on his shoulder again. He found Thorn and Talmanes mounted at the front of the camp along with a force of fifty Redarms. Thorn wore an extravagant wine-red coat and trousers, gold work at the arms, with a shirt bearing white lace at the cuffs and a silken cravat tied at the neck. The buttons were of gleaming gold. His mustaches had been trimmed and neatly combed. The entire outfit was new, including the black cloak, its inner lining of gold.

mæt fɹoʊz ɪn pleɪs. haʊ hæd ðə mæn soʊ pɝfəkli tʃɹænsfɔɹm fɹəm ən oʊl skæmp ʌv ə ɡlimən ɪndə ə ɹɔɪəl kɔɹɾiɝ? laɪt!

Mat froze in place. How had the man so perfectly transformed from an old scamp of a gleeman into a royal courtier? Light!

"aɪ si fɹəm jəɹ ɹiækʃən ðət ðə pɹɛzənteɪʃən ɪz ɪfɛktɪv," θɔɹn sɛd.

"I see from your reaction that the presentation is effective," Thorn said.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" mæt ɪkskleɪmd. "wʌt hæpənd? dɪd jə teɪk ɪl fɹəm ə bæd sɔsədʒ ət bɹɛkfəst?"

"Blood and bloody ashes!" Mat exclaimed. "What happened? Did you take ill from a bad sausage at breakfast?"

θɔɹn wɪpt ɪz kloʊk bæk, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðəɾ i hæɾ ɪz hɑɹp aʊɾ ən əɾ ɪz saɪd. hi lʊk laɪk ə kɔɹt-bɑɹd! "aɪ fɪɡjɝd ðəɾ ɪf - æftɝ ɔl ə ðiz jɪɹz - aɪ wɑz gɑnə meɪk ən əpɪɹəns ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, aɪ ʃəd lʊk ðə pɑɹt."

Thorn whipped his cloak back, revealing that he had his harp out and at his side. He looked like a court-bard! "I figured that if - after all of these years - I was going to make an appearance in Caemlyn, I should look the part."

"noʊ wʌndɝ juv bɪn sɪŋɪŋ fəɹ kɔɪn ɛvɹi deɪ," mæt sɛd. "ðə pipəl ɪn ðoʊz tævɝnz əv weɪ tu mʌtʃ mʌni."

"No wonder you've been singing for coin every day," Mat said. "The people in those taverns have way too much money."

tælmɑnz ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ - əz ɡʊɾ əz ə ɡɹɪn, fɹəm ðət mæn. ət taɪmz, hi sim soʊ daʊɝ əz tə meɪk θʌndɝklaʊdz fil tʃɪɹfəl. hi ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə faɪn aʊtfɪt, hɪz ə dip koʊbɔlt ən sɪlvɝ. mæt fɛlt əɾ ɪz kʌfs. hi cʊɾə juz səm leɪs. ɪf ləpɪn hæd bɪn hɪɹ, hi wʊɾə sɛɾ aʊt ðə pɹɑpɝ aʊtfɪt wɪθaʊt mæt ivən æskɪŋ. ə lɪɾəl leɪs wɑz ɡʊd fəɹ ə mæn. meɪɾ ɪm lʊk pɹəzɛntəbəl.

Talmanes raised an eyebrow - as good as a grin, from that man. At times, he seemed so dour as to make thunderclouds feel cheerful. He also wore a fine outfit, his of deep cobalt and silver. Mat felt at his cuffs. He could have used some lace. If Lopin had been here, he would have set out the proper outfit without Mat even asking. A little lace was good for a man. Made him look presentable.
