ɪz ðət wʌt jəɹ wɛɹɪŋ tə vɪzət ðə kwin, mæt?" tælmɑnz æskt. "ʌv kɔɹs ɪɾ ɪz." ðə wɝdz lɛft ɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ i hæɾ ə tʃæns tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðɛm. "ɪts ə ɡʊd koʊt." hi wɔkt oʊvɝ tə teɪk pɪps' ɹeɪnz, "ɡʊd fəɹ spɑɹɪŋ ɪn, meɪbi," tælmɑnz sɛd.

Is that what you're wearing to visit the Queen, Mat?" Talmanes asked. "Of course it is." The words left his mouth before he had a chance to think about them. "It's a good coat." He walked over to take Pips' reins, "Good for sparring in, maybe," Talmanes said.

"ɪleɪn ɪz ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ naʊ, mæt," θɔɹn sɛd. "æn kwinz ɑɹ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ lɑt. jə ʃəd ʃoʊ hɝ ɹɪspɛkt."

"Elayne is the Queen of Andor now, Mat," Thorn said. "And queens are a particular lot. You should show her respect."

"aɪ æm ʃoʊɪŋ əɹ blʌɾi ɹɪspɛkt," mæt sɛd, hændɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ tə wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz, ðən klaɪmɪŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. hi tʊk ðə spɪɹ bæk, ðən tɝn pɪps soʊ hi kəd ɹəɡɑɹd θɔɹn. "ðɪs ɪz ə ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf koʊt fəɹ ə fɑɹmɝ."

"I am showing her bloody respect," Mat said, handing his spear to one of the soldiers, then climbing into the saddle. He took the spear back, then turned Pips so he could regard Thorn. "This is a good enough coat for a farmer."

"jɔɹ nɑɾ ə fɑɹmɝ ɛnimɔɹ, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd.

"You're not a farmer anymore, Mat," Talmanes said.

"aɪ æm tu," mæt sɛd stʌbɝnli.

"I am too," Mat said stubbornly.

"bʌt mjuzənʒ kɔl jə - " θɔɹn bɪɡæn.

"But Musenge called you - " Thorn began.

"hi wɑz mɪsteɪkən," mæt sɛd. "dʒʌs kəz ə mæn mɛɹiz sʌmwʌn dʌzn min i sʌɾənli bɪkʌmz blʌɾi noʊbɪləɾi."

"He was mistaken," Mat said. "Just because a man marries someone doesn't mean he suddenly becomes bloody nobility."

θɔɹn ən tælmɑnz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə lʊk.

Thorn and Talmanes exchanged a look.

"mæt," θɔɹn sɛd. "ðæts æktʃəli  ɪɡzækli haʊ ɪt wɝks. ɪts pɹɪɾi mʌtʃ wʌn ə ði oʊnli weɪz tə bɪkʌm noʊbɪləɾi."

"Mat," Thorn said. "That's actually exactly how it works. It's pretty much one of the only ways to become nobility."

"ðæts ðə weɪ wi də ɪt hɪɹ, meɪbi," mæt sɛd. "bʌt tuɑn ɪz fɹəm sintʃæn. hu noʊz wʌt ðeɪ də ðɛɹ? wi ɔl noʊ haʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ ðeɪ kən bi. wi kænt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl wi tɔk tə hɝ."

"That's the way we do it here, maybe," Mat said. "But Tuon is from Seanchan. Who knows what they do there? We all know how strange they can be. We can't know anything until we talk to her."

θɔɹn fɹaʊnd. "aɪm sɝɾən, fɹəm θɪŋz ʃi sɛd, ðət - "

Thorn frowned. "I'm certain, from things she said, that - "

"wi kænt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl wi tɔk tə tuɑn," mæt ɹɪpiɾɪd, laʊɾɝ ðɪs taɪm. "əntɪl ðɛn, aɪm mæt. nʌn ə ðɪs pɹɪns ʌv wʌtɛvɝ nɑnsɛns."

"We can't know anything until we talk to Tuon," Mat repeated, louder this time. "Until then, I'm Mat. None of this Prince of Whatever nonsense."

θɔɹn lʊkt kənfjuzd, bʌt tælmɑnz' lɪps tɝn ɛvɝ soʊ slaɪtli ʌp ət ðə saɪd. bɝn ðət mæn.

Thorn looked confused, but Talmanes' lips turned ever so slightly up at the side. Burn that man.

mæt wɑz ɪnklaɪn tə θɪŋk ɪz sɑləm neɪtʃɝ wɑz ɔl ən ækt. wɑz i sikɹɪtli læfɪŋ ɪnsaɪd?

Mat was inclined to think his solemn nature was all an act. Was he secretly laughing inside?

"wɛl, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, "ju nɛvɝ əv meɪɾ ɛni sɛns, soʊ waɪ ʃəd wi ɪkspɛk jə tə naʊ? ɔnwɝd, ðɛn, tə mit ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ. sɝɾən jə doʊnt wɑnə ɹoʊl ɪn ðə mʌd fɝst?"

"Well, Mat," Talmanes said, "you never have made any sense, so why should we expect you to now? Onward, then, to meet the Queen of Andor. Certain you don't want to roll in the mud first?"

"aɪl bi faɪn," mæt sɛd dʒɹaɪli, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæt daʊn əz ə soʊlʒɝ taɪɾ ɪz pæk tə ðə bæk ə hɪz sæɾəl.

"I'll be fine," Mat said dryly, pulling his hat down as a soldier tied his pack to the back of his saddle.

hi kɪk pɪps ɪndə moʊʃən, ən ðə pɹəsɛʃən bɪɡæn ðə naʊ-fəmɪljɝ ɹaɪd tə keɪɛmlɪn. mæt spɛn moʊst ə ðə taɪm ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz plæn ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi hæɾ ɑlʌdʒɹəz peɪpɝz tʌkt ɪndə ə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ, ən ðeɪ ɪnkluɾəd əɹ dɪmænz. ɛvɹi bɛlfndɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, lɑɹdʒ kwɑntəɾiz əɹ bɹɑnz ən aɪɝn, ən paʊɾɝz wɝθ θaʊzənz ə kɹaʊnz. ən ʃi kleɪm ðət wɑz ðə mɪnəməm ʌv wʌt ʃi niɾəd.

He kicked Pips into motion, and the procession began the now-familiar ride to Caemlyn. Mat spent most of the time going over his plan in his head. He had Aludra's papers tucked into a leather folder, and they included her demands. Every bellfounder in Caemlyn, large quantities or bronze and iron, and powders worth thousands of crowns. And she claimed that was the minimum of what she needed.

haʊ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wɑz mæt gɑnə ɡɛt blʌɾi ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən tə ɡɪv ɪm ɔl ðæt? hi wəɾ əv tə də ə lɑɾ ə smaɪlɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd pɹuvən ɹɪzɪstən tə hɪz smaɪlz bɪfɔɹ, ən kwinz wɝ nɑt laɪk ɔɹɾənɛɹi foʊk. moʊst wɪmən, ðeɪ wəd smaɪl bæk əɹ ðeɪ wəd skaʊl ət ju, soʊ jə nu wɛɹ jə stʊd. ɪleɪn sim ðə taɪp tə smaɪl ət ju, ðən tɔs jə ɪn pɹɪzən ɔl ðə seɪm.

How under the Light was Mat going to get bloody Elayne Trakand to give him all that? He would have to do a lot of smiling. But Elayne had proven resistant to his smiles before, and Queens were not like ordinary folk. Most women, they would smile back or they would scowl at you, so you knew where you stood. Elayne seemed the type to smile at you, then toss you in prison all the same.

fəɹ wʌns, ɪt wəd bi naɪs ɪf ɪz lʌk kəd si hɪm ɔf sʌmwɛɹ ɛndʒɔɪ-paɪp ən ə ɡeɪm ə daɪs, wɪð ə pɹɪɾi sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl ɑn ɪz ni ən noʊ bɪɑn ɪz nɛks θɹoʊ. ɪnstɛd, hi wɑz mɛɹid tə ə sintʃæn haɪ blʌɾ ən wɑz ɔf tə bɛɡ ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ fəɹ əɹ hɛlp. haʊ dɪɾ i ɡɛt ðiz sɪtʃueɪʃənz? səmtaɪmz i θɔt ðət ðə kɹieɪɾɝ mʌs bi laɪk tælmɑnz. stʃɹeɪɾ ə feɪs, bʌt sikɹɪtli hævɪŋ ə ɡɹæn taɪm læfɪŋ ət mæt.

For once, it would be nice if his luck could see him off somewhere enjoy-pipe and a game of dice, with a pretty serving girl on his knee and no beyond his next throw. Instead, he was married to a Seanchan High Blood and was off to beg the Queen of Andor for her help. How did he get these situations? Sometimes he thought that the Creator must be like Talmanes. Straight of face, but secretly having a grand time laughing at Mat.

hɪz pɹəsɛʃən pæs numɝəs kæmps ɑn ði oʊpən pleɪnz ɝaʊn keɪɛmlɪn. ɔl mɝsənɛɹiz wɝ ɹikwaɪɝd tə steɪ ət list ə liɡ əweɪ, bʌt ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə lɔɹdz kəd kæmp kloʊsɝ. ðət pʊt mæt ɪn ə ɹʌf pleɪs. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz tɛnʃən bɪtwin sɛl-sɔɹdz ən lɔɪəl ɑɹmmɪn, ən wɪð ðə mɝsənɛɹiz soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, faɪts wɝ kɑmən. ðə bænd wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt.

His procession passed numerous camps on the open plains around Caemlyn. All mercenaries were required to stay at least a league away, but the forces of the lords could camp closer. That put Mat in a rough place. There was always tension between sell-swords and loyal armsmen, and with the mercenaries so far from Caemlyn, fights were common. The Band was right in the middle of it.

hi dɪd səm kwɪk fɪɡjɝɪŋ beɪst ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪlz ə kæmpfaɪɝ smoʊk i sɔ twɪstɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

He did some quick figuring based on the trails of campfire smoke he saw twisting into the air.

ðəɹ wɝ ət lis tɛn θaʊzən mɝsənɛɹiz ɪn ði ɛɹiə. dɪɾ ɪleɪn noʊ wʌɾ ə bʌbəlɪŋ kɛɾəl ʃi wɑz bɹuɪŋ hɪɹ? tu mʌtʃ hit, ən ðə hoʊl blʌɾi θɪŋ wəd bɔɪl oʊvɝ!

There were at least ten thousand mercenaries in the area. Did Elayne know what a bubbling kettle she was brewing here? Too much heat, and the whole bloody thing would boil over!

mæts pɹəsɛʃən dʒɹu ətɛnʃən. hi hæd wʌn ə ðə mɛn flaɪɪŋ ðə bænɝ ə ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd, ən ɪz mɛn wɝ dɪvɛləpɪŋ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. baɪ mæts kaʊnt, ðeɪ wɝ ðə lɑɹdʒəst sɪŋɡəl ɡɹup -  mɝsənɛɹi əɹ lɔɹdz fɔɹs - aʊtsaɪd keɪɛmlɪnz wɔlz. ðeɪ wɝ əz ɔɹɡənaɪzd ən dɪsəplən əz ə ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɑɹmi, ən wɝ ʌndɝ ðə liɾɝʃɪp ʌv ə pɝsənəl fɹɛn ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hɪz mɛn kəd nɑt hɛlp bɹæɡɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt, ðoʊ mæt wəd mʌtʃ ɹæðɝ ðət ðeɪ hæd kɛp kwaɪət.

Mat's procession drew attention. He had one of the men flying the banner of the Band of the Red Hand, and his men were developing a reputation. By Mat's count, they were the largest single group -  mercenary or lord's force - outside Caemlyn's walls. They were as organized and disciplined as a regular army, and were under the leadership of a personal friend of the Dragon Reborn. His men could not help bragging about that, though Mat would much rather that they had kept quiet.

ðeɪ pæst ɡɹups ə mɛn weɪɾɪŋ baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd, kjʊɹiəs tə kætʃ ə ɡlɪmps ʌv "lɔɹd mæt." hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz fɔɹwɝd. ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd səm fɑp ɪn ə ɹɪtʃ koʊt, ðən ðeɪ wəd bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪd! ðoʊ pɝhæps i cʊɾə tʃoʊzən ə bɛɾɝ koʊt. ðɪs wʌn wɑz stɪf, ən ðə kɑlɝ ɪtʃt.

They passed groups of men waiting by the side of the road, curious to catch a glimpse of "Lord Mat." He kept his eyes forward. If they had expected some fop in a rich coat, then they would be disappointed! Though perhaps he could have chosen a better coat. This one was stiff, and the collar itched.

ʌv kɔɹs, mɔɹ ðən ə fju sim tə θɪŋk tælmɑnz wɑz "lɔɹd mæt" fɹəm ðə weɪ ðeɪ pɔɪntəd, pɹɑbli kəz ə haʊ hi wɑz dʒɹɛst. blʌɾi æʃəz!

Of course, more than a few seemed to think Talmanes was "Lord Mat" from the way they pointed, probably because of how he was dressed. Bloody ashes!

ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ɪleɪn wɑz gɑnə bi tʌf. bʌt mæt hæɾ ə hɪɾən kɑɹd, wʌn i hoʊpt wəd bi ɪnʌf tə ɡɛɾ əɹ tə lʊk pæs ði ɪkspɛns ʌv ɑlʌdʒɹəz pɹəpoʊzəl. ðoʊ hi wɑz mɔɹ əfɹeɪd ʃi wəd si wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ ən wɑnə teɪk pɑɹɾ ɪn ɪt. ən wən ə wʊmən wɑntəd tə bi pɑɹt"

This conversation with Elayne was going to be tough. But Mat had a hidden card, one he hoped would be enough to get her to look past the expense of Aludra's proposal. Though he was more afraid she would see what he was doing and want to take part in it. And when a woman wanted to be part"

ʌv sʌmθɪŋ, ðət mɛnt ʃi wɑntəd tə bi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ.

of something, that meant she wanted to be in charge.

ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪnz waɪt-ɡɹeɪ wɔlz, pæsɪŋ ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ aʊɾɝ sɪɾi. ðə soʊlʒɝz weɪvd ɪm ɑn. mæt ɡeɪv əm ə tɪp ə ðə hæt, ən tɑm ɡeɪv ə flɝɪʃɪŋ weɪv tə ðə smɔl kɹaʊd ɡæðɝd hɪɹ. ðeɪ tʃɪɹd. ɡɹeɪt. dʒʌs blʌɾi ɡɹeɪt.

They approached the gate in Caemlyn's white-gray walls, passing the growing outer city. The soldiers waved him on. Mat gave them a tip of the hat, and Thom gave a flourishing wave to the small crowd gathered here. They cheered. Great. Just bloody great.

ðə mɑɹtʃ θɹu ðə nu sɪɾi wɑz ʌnivɛnfəl seɪv fəɹ mɔɹ kɹaʊdz wɑtʃɪŋ. wəd sʌmwʌn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪz feɪs fɹəm ðoʊz dʒɹɔɪŋz? mæt wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ ɔf ðə meɪn θɝoʊfɛɹz, bʌt keɪɛmlɪnz nɛɹoʊ stʃɹits wɝ ə twɪstɪŋ mɛs. ə fɔɹs ə fɪfti hɔɹsmən wɑz tu lɑɹdʒ tə muv tfɪɹaʊ ðoʊz stʃɹits.

The march through the New City was uneventful save for more crowds watching. Would someone recognize his face from those drawings? Mat wanted to get off the main thoroughfares, but Caemlyn's narrow streets were a twisting mess. A force of fifty horsemen was too large to move tfirough those streets.

ðeɪ ɪvɛntʃəwəli pæs θɹu ðə bɹɪljənt waɪt wɔlz ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, wɛɹ ðə ɹoʊdz wɝ waɪɾɝ, ði oʊɡiɝ-bɪl bɪldɪŋz lɛs kɹæmpt, ən ðə pɑpjəleɪʃən θɪnɝ. hɪɹ, ðeɪ pæs mɔɹ ɡɹups ʌv ɑɹmd mɛn,' ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɪn waɪɾ ən ɹɛd. mæt kəd meɪk ðɛɹ kæmp aʊɾ əhɛd, kʌvɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɪð ðɛɹ tɛns ən hɔɹslaɪnz.

They eventually passed through the brilliant white walls of the Inner City, where the roads were wider, the Ogier-built buildings less cramped, and the population thinner. Here, they passed more groups of armed men,' including Guardsmen in white and red. Mat could make their camp out ahead, covering the gray paving stones of the courtyard with their tents and horselines.

ðə keɪɛmlɪn pæləs wɑz laɪk ənʌðɝ lɪɾəl sɪɾi wɪðɪn ðə sɪɾi ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ɪt hæɾ ə loʊ fɔɹɾəfaɪd wɔl, ən waɪl ɪts piks ən spaɪɹz ɹoʊz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ɪt hæd mɔɹ ə ðə lʊk ʌv ə wɔɹ bʌŋkɝ ðən ðə sʌn pæləs dɪd. ɑd, haʊ hi hæd nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ðət wən i wɑz jʌŋɡɝ. ɪf keɪɛmlɪn fɛl ðɪs pæləs kəd hoʊld ɑn ɪts oʊn. ðeɪ niɾəd mɔɹ bæɹəks, ðoʊ, wɪðɪn ðət wɔl. ðɪs kæmpɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs.

The Caemlyn palace was like another little city within the city inside the city. It had a low fortified wall, and while its peaks and spires rose into the air, it had more of the look of a war bunker than the Sun Palace did. Odd, how he had never noticed that when he was younger. If Caemlyn fell this palace could hold on its own. They needed more barracks, though, within that wall. This camping out in the courtyard was ridiculous.

mæt tʊk tælmɑnz, θɔɹn ən ə fɔɹs ə tɛn ɹɛdʒɹmz əz ən ɛskɔɹt. ə tɔl mæn ɪn ə bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt, θɹi ɡoʊldən nɑts ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ə hɪz kloʊk, weɪɾəd ət ðə pæləs ɛntʃɹəns. hi wɑz ə jʌŋ mæn, bʌt ðə weɪ hi stʊd - ɹɪlækst, jɛt pɔɪzd, hæn ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd -  ɪndəkeɪɾəd i wɑz ə pɹæktəst soʊlʒɝ. tu bæɾ i hæd sətʃ ə pɹɪɾi feɪs. ə laɪf ɪn ðə mɪlətɛɹi wəd pɹɑbli ɛn ʌp ɹɛkɪŋ ðæt.

Mat took Talmanes, Thorn and a force of ten Redarms as an escort. A tall man in a burnished breastplate, three golden knots on the shoulder of his cloak, waited at the palace entrance. He was a young man, but the way he stood - relaxed, yet poised, hand on the pommel of his sword -  indicated he was a practiced soldier. Too bad he had such a pretty face. A life in the military would probably end up wrecking that.

ðə mæn nɑɾəd tə mæt, θɔɹn ən tælmɑnz. "lɔɹd kɔθən?" hi æsk mæt.

The man nodded to Mat, Thorn and Talmanes. "Lord Cauthon?" he asked Mat.

"dʒʌs mæt."

"Just Mat."

ðə mæn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. "maɪ neɪm ɪz ɑɹlz ɡaɪbɑn. əl lɛd jə tə hɝ mædʒəsti."

The man raised an eyebrow, but said nothing. "My name is Charlz Guybon. I'll lead you to Her Majesty."

ʃi hæd sɛnt ɡaɪbɑn hɪmsɛlf tə ɛskɔɹt mæt. hi wɑz haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ, sɛkənd-ɪn-kəmæn ə ði ɑɹmiz. ðət wɑz ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. wɑz ɪleɪn əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪm, əɹ wɑz ʃi wɑz ɑnɝɪŋ hɪm? meɪbi ɡaɪbɑn hæd wɑntəd tə si mæt fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. ʃi wəd nɑɾ ɑnɝ mæt, nɑɾ æftɝ meɪkɪŋ ɪm weɪt soʊ lɔŋ tə ɡɛɾ ən ɑɾiəns! ə faɪn ɡɹiɾɪŋ fəɹ ən oʊl fɹɛnd. hɪz səspɪʃənz wɝ kənfɝmd wən ɡaɪbɑn dɪd nɑt lɛɾ əm tə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl, bʌt daʊn tə ə kwaɪəɾ ɛɹiə ʌv ðə pæləs.

She had sent Guybon himself to escort Mat. He was high-ranking, second-in-command of the armies. That was unexpected. Was Elayne afraid of him, or was she was honoring him? Maybe Guybon had wanted to see Mat for himself. She would not honor Mat, not after making him wait so long to get an audience! A fine greeting for an old friend. His suspicions were confirmed when Guybon did not lead them to the Grand Hall, but down to a quiet area of the Palace.

"aɪv hɝd mʌtʃ əbaʊt ju, mæstɝ kɔθən," ɡaɪbɑn sɛd. hi sim laɪk wʌn ə ðoʊz stɪf soʊlʒɝz. sɑləd, bʌt meɪbi ə lɪɾəl tu sɑləd-laɪk ə baʊ wɪθaʊɾ ɪnʌf spɹɪŋ tə ɪt.

"I've heard much about you, Master Cauthon," Guybon said. He seemed like one of those stiff soldiers. Solid, but maybe a little too solid-Like a bow without enough spring to it.

"fɹʌm hu?" mæt æskt. "ɪleɪn?"

"From who?" Mat asked. "Elayne?"

"moʊsli ɹumɝz ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi. pipəl laɪk tə tɔk əbaʊt ju."

"Mostly rumors around the city. People like to talk about you."

ðeɪ du? mæt θɔt. "aɪ dɪdn də hæf ʌv wʌt ðeɪ seɪ," hi ɡɹʌmbəld, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf wɑzn maɪ blʌɾi fɔlt." ɡaɪbɑn læft. "wʌɾ ə ðə stɔɹi ʌv jə hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə tʃɹi fəɹ naɪn deɪz?"

They do? Mat thought. "I didn't do half of what they say," he grumbled, and the other half wasn't my bloody fault." Guybon laughed. "What of the story of you hanging from a tree for nine days?"

"dɪdn hæpən," mæt sɛd, ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ði ɝdʒ tə tʌɡ ət ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. naɪn deɪz? wɛɹ dɪd ðət kʌm fɹʌm? hi hæd nɑɾ ivən hʌŋ fəɹ naɪn blʌɾi mɪnəts! naɪn sɛkənz hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ.

"Didn't happen," Mat said, resisting the urge to tug at the scarf around his neck. Nine days? Where did that come from? He had not even hung for nine bloody minutes! Nine seconds had been too long.

"ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ seɪ," ɡaɪbɑn kəntɪnjud, "ðæt jə nɛvɝ luz ət daɪs əɹ ət lʌv, ən ðət jəɹ spɪɹ nɛvɝ mɪsəz ɪts tɑɹɡət."

"They also say," Guybon continued, "that you never lose at dice or at love, and that your spear never misses its target."

"wɪʃ ðoʊz sɛkən tu wɝ tʃɹu. bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ ðeɪ wɝ."

"Wish those second two were true. Burn me, but I wish they were."

"bʌt jə də ɔlweɪz wɪn ət daɪs?"

"But you do always win at dice?"

"nɪɹ ɪnʌf," mæt sɛd, tʌɡɪŋ daʊn ðə bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt. "bʌt doʊn spɹɛd ðət wʌn, əɹ əl nɛvɝ faɪn ə ɡeɪm."

"Near enough," Mat said, tugging down the brim of his hat. "But don't spread that one, or I'll never find a game."

"ðeɪ seɪ jə slu wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ɡaɪbɑn noʊɾəd.

"They say you slew one of the Forsaken," Guybon noted.

"nɑt tʃɹu," mæt sɛd. wɛɹ hæd ðət wʌn kʌm fɹʌm?

"Not true," Mat said. Where had that one come from?

"æn ðə stɔɹiz ə jə dulɪŋ ðə kɪŋ ə ði il ɪnveɪɾɝz ɪn ə bæɾəl ʌv ɑnɝ? dɪd jə ɹɪli wɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ðə lɔɪəlti ʌv ði il?"

"And the stories of you dueling the King of the Aiel invaders in a battle of honor? Did you really win the Dragon Reborn the loyalty of the Aiel?"

"blʌɾi æʃəz," mæt sɛd. "aɪ kɪl kaʊulɑɾɪn, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn hæpən ɪn ɛni kaɪndə duəl! aɪ ɹæn ɪndə hɪm ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild, ən wʌn ʌv əs hæd tə daɪ. ɪt wɑzn blʌɾi wɛl gɑnə bi mi."

"Bloody ashes," Mat said. "I killed Couladin, but it didn't happen in any kind of duel! I ran into him on the battlefield, and one of us had to die. It wasn't bloody well going to be me."

"ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," ɡaɪbɑn sɛd. "aɪ θɔt ðət wʌn maɪt bi tʃɹu. ət list, ɪts wʌn ə ðə fju ðət kəɾ əv hæpənd. ənlaɪk. . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf.

"Interesting," Guybon said. "I thought that one might be true. At least, it's one of the few that could have happened. Unlike. . . ." He trailed off.

"wʌt?" mæt sɛd. ðeɪ pæst ən ɪntɝsɛkʃən ə hɔlz wɛɹ sɝvəns ɡɹupt, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ən ði ʌðɝ pæs ən wɪspɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz.

"What?" Mat said. They passed an intersection of halls where servants grouped, watching him and the other pass and whispering among themselves.

ɡaɪbɑn lʊk hɛzɪɾənt. "aɪm ʃʊɹ juv hɝd."

Guybon looked hesitant. "I'm sure you've heard."

"daʊtfəl." bɝn hɪm! wʌt wɑz nɛkst? hæd ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə bæn bɪn spɹɛɾɪŋ ðiz ɹumɝz? ivən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ əbaʊt səm ə ðoʊz θɪŋz!

"Doubtful." Burn him! What was next? Had the members of the Band been spreading these rumors? Even they did not know about some of those things!

wɛl, ðɛɹz ðɪs ɹumɝ ðət sɛz jə stɛpt ɪndə dɛθs doʊmeɪn tə tʃælənʒ ɪm ən dɪmæn ænsɝz tə jəɹ kwɛstʃənz," ɡaɪbɑn sɛd, lʊk-ɪŋ mɔɹ ɪmbɛɹəst. "æn ðəɾ i ɡeɪv jə ðət spɪɹ jə hoʊld ən fɔɹtoʊl tə jə jəɹ oʊn dɛθ."

Well, there's this rumor that says you stepped into death's domain to challenge him and demand answers to your questions," Guybon said, look-ing more embarrassed. "And that he gave you that spear you hold and foretold to you your own death."

mæt fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ðət wʌn wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ðə tʃɹuθ tə bi fɹaɪɾənɪŋ. sɪli, aɪ noʊ," ɡaɪbɑn sɛd.

Mat felt a chill. That one was close enough to the truth to be frightening. Silly, I know," Guybon said.

ʃʊɹ," mæt sɛd. "sɪli." hi tʃɹaɪd tə læf, bʌɾ ɪt keɪm aʊɾ əz ə kɑf. ɡaɪbɑn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm kjʊɹiəsli.

Sure," Mat said. "Silly." He tried to laugh, but it came out as a cough. Guybon regarded him curiously.

laɪt, mæt ɹilaɪzd, hi θɪŋks aɪm dɑdʒɪŋ ðə kwɛstʃən! "oʊnli ɹumɝz, ʌv kɔɹs, mæt sɛd kwɪkli.

Light, Mat realized, he thinks I'm dodging the question! "Only rumors, of course, Mat said quickly.

tu kwɪkli, meɪbi. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!

Too quickly, maybe. Blood and bloody ashes!

ɡaɪbɑn nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəl.

Guybon nodded, looking thoughtful.

mæt wɑntəd tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə tɑpɪk, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs hɪmsɛlf tə oʊpən ɪz blʌɾi maʊθ. hi kəd si ðət mɔɹ ən mɔɹ pæləs sɝvəns hæd stɑp tə wɑtʃ ðə pɹəsɛʃən. hi fɛlt laɪk kɝsɪŋ səm mɔɹ ət θɑɹ bʌt ðən noʊɾəst ðət mɛni ʌv əm sim foʊkəst ɑn θɔɹn.

Mat wanted to change the topic, but he did not trust himself to open his bloody mouth. He could see that more and more palace servants had stopped to watch the procession. He felt like cursing some more at thar but then noticed that many of them seemed focused on Thorn.

θɔɹn hæd bɪn kɔɹt-bɑɹd ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. hi dɪd nɑt tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt mæt nu hi hæd sʌfɝɾ ə fɔlɪŋ-aʊt wɪð ðə kwin θɔɹn hæd bɪn ɪn vɝtʃuəl ɛɡzaɪl ɛvɝ sɪns, kʌmɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn oʊnli wən pɹɛst.

Thorn had been court-bard right here in Caemlyn. He did not talk about it, but Mat knew he had suffered a falling-out with the Queen Thorn had been in virtual exile ever since, coming to Caemlyn only when pressed.

mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz dɛd naʊ, soʊ ðɪs wɑz θɔɹn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɛɡzaɪl ɪt simd. ðət wɑz pɹɑbli waɪ hi hæd dʒɹɛst soʊ faɪnli. mæt lʊk daʊn əɾ ɪz koʊɾ əɡɛn. bɝn mi, aɪ ʃʊɾə wɔɹn sʌmθɪŋ naɪsɝ.

Morgase was dead now, so this was Thorn returning from his exile it seemed. That was probably why he had dressed so finely. Mat looked down at his coat again. Burn me, I should have worn something nicer.

ɡaɪbɑn lɛɾ əm tə ə kɑɹvd wʊɾən dɔɹ, bɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɔɹɪŋ laɪən ʌv ændɝ. hi nɑk sɔfli, ɹəsiv ðə kɔl tə ɛntɝ, ðən dʒɛstʃɝd mæt təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ. "ðə kwin wɪl ɹəsiv jə ɪn əɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum."

Guybon led them to a carved wooden door, bearing the roaring Lion of Andor. He knocked softly, received the call to enter, then gestured Mat toward the door. "The Queen will receive you in her sitting room."

"θɔɹn, jəɹ wɪð mi," mæt sɛd. "tælmɑnz, jə wɑtʃ ðə soʊlʒɝz." ðə noʊbəlmən lʊkt kɹɛstfɔlən, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz əndaʊɾɪdli gɑnə ɪmbɛɹəs mæt, ən i dɪd nɑt wɑn tælmɑnz ðəɹ tə si. "aɪl ɪntʃɹədus jə leɪɾɝ," mæt pɹɑməst. blʌɾi noʊbəlmən. ðeɪ θɔɾ ɛvɹi sɛkən θɪŋ wɑz ən əfɹʌn tə ðɛɹ ɑnɝ. mæt wʊɾə bɪn hæpi tə weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd!

"Thorn, you're with me," Mat said. "Talmanes, you watch the soldiers." The nobleman looked crestfallen, but Elayne was undoubtedly going to embarrass Mat, and he did not want Talmanes there to see. "I'll introduce you later," Mat promised. Bloody noblemen. They thought every second thing was an affront to their honor. Mat would have been happy to wait outside!

mæt stɛpt ʌp tə ðə dɔɹ, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ. hi hæd fɔɾ ɪn dʌzənz ə skɝmɪʃɪz ən bæɾəlz wɪθaʊt ɡɹoʊɪŋ nɝvəs. naʊ hɪz hænz wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ. waɪ dɪɾ i fil əz ɪf i wɝ wɔkɪŋ dɝɛkli ɪndə ən æmbʊʃ wɪθaʊɾ ə skɹæp ʌv ɑɹmɝ ɑn?

Mat stepped up to the door, taking a deep breath. He had fought in dozens of skirmishes and battles without growing nervous. Now his hands were shaking. Why did he feel as if he were walking directly into an ambush without a scrap of armor on?

ɪleɪn. əz kwin. bɝn hɪm, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɝt. hi oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn.

Elayne. As Queen. Burn him, but this was going to hurt. He opened the door and strode in.

hɪz aɪz faʊn ɪleɪn ɪmiɾiətli. ʃi sæt bɪsaɪɾ ə hɑɹθ, hoʊldɪŋ ə kʌp ʌv wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi mɪlk. ʃi lʊkt ɹeɪɾiənt ɪn ə ɡaʊn ə dip ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. bjuɾəfəl, fʊl ɹɛd lɪps ðət mæt wəd nɑɾ əv maɪndəd kɪsɪŋ, ɪf i hæd nɑt bɪn ə mɛɹid mæn. hɝ ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ sim tə ʃɪmɝ ɪn ðə hɑɹθlaɪt, ən əɹ tʃiks wɝ fʊl ə kʌlɝ. ʃi sim tə hæv ɡeɪn ə lɪɾəl weɪt. bɛs nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðæt. əɹ ʃəd hi? səmtaɪmz wɪmən ɡɑɾ æŋɡɹi wən jə mɛnʃən ðət ðeɪ lʊk dɪfɹənt, ən səmtaɪmz ðeɪ ɡɑɾ æŋɡɹi ɪf jə dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs.

His eyes found Elayne immediately. She sat beside a hearth, holding a cup of what appeared to be milk. She looked radiant in a gown of deep red and gold. Beautiful, full red lips that Mat would not have minded kissing, if he had not been a married man. Her red-gold hair seemed to shimmer in the hearthlight, and her cheeks were full of color. She seemed to have gained a little weight. Best not to mention that. Or should he? Sometimes women got angry when you mentioned that they looked different, and sometimes they got angry if you did not notice.

ʃi wɑz ə pɹɪɾi θɪŋ. nɑɾ əz pɹɪɾi əz tuɑn, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪleɪn wɑz fɑɹ tu peɪl, ən tu tɔl, ən hæd tu mʌtʃ hɛɹ. ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ. stɪl, ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi. simd ə weɪst əz ə kwin. ʃi wʊɾə meɪɾ ən ɛksələn sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl. ɑ wɛl. sʌmbɑɾi hæd tə bi kwin.

She was a pretty thing. Not as pretty as Tuon, of course. Elayne was far too pale, and too tall, and had too much hair. It was distracting. Still, she was pretty. Seemed a waste as a queen. She would have made an excellent serving girl. Ah well. Somebody had to be Queen.

mæt ɡlænst ət bɝdʒɪt, hu wɑz ði oʊnli ʌðɝ wʌn ɪn ðə ɹum. ʃi lʊk ðə seɪm. ɔlweɪz dɪd, wɪð ðət ɡoʊldən bɹeɪɾ ən haɪ buts, laɪk ðə hɪɹoʊ fɹəm ðə blʌɾi stɔɹiz. wɪtʃ wɑz ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃi wɑz. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si hɝ əɡɛn;

Mat glanced at Birgitte, who was the only other one in the room. She looked the same. Always did, with that golden braid and high boots, like the hero from the bloody stories. Which was exactly what she was. It was good to see her again;

ʃi wɑz wʌn wʊmən i nu hu wəd nɑt snæp əɾ ɪm fəɹ spikɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ.

she was one woman he knew who would not snap at him for speaking the truth.

θɔɹn stɛpt ɪn bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən mæt klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. ʃi wəɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə bi fɔɹməl.

Thorn stepped in beside him, and Mat cleared his throat. She would expected him to be formal.

wɛl, hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə baʊ əɹ skɹeɪp, ən ɪleɪn lɛpt aʊɾ ə hɝ tʃɛɹ. ʃi ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə ɹum əz bɝdʒɪt kloʊz ðə dɔɹ. "θɔɹn, aɪm soʊ ɡlæd ðət jəɹ ɔl ɹaɪt!" ɪleɪn ɡɹæbd ɪm ɪn ən ɛmbɹeɪs.

Well, he was not going to bow or scrape, and Elayne leaped out of her chair. She ran across the room as Birgitte closed the door. "Thorn, I'm so glad that you're all right!" Elayne grabbed him in an embrace.

Burn me, Elayne, but we're going to be at a disadvantage. The Shadow can always toss more Trollocs at us than we have soldiers, and the bloody things are twice as hard to kill as a man. hi kʌt hɪmsɛlf ɔf. hi hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə seɪ hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə tʃɹoʊl-lɑk wɔɹz, wɪtʃ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə. ə mæn kəd stɑɹt səm ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ ɹumɝz ðət weɪ. "lʊk," hi sɛd. "aɪ noʊ ðɪs saʊnz aʊtʃɹeɪdʒəs, bʌt juv tə ɡɪv ɪɾ ə tʃæns."

He cut himself off. He had been about to say he remembered the Trol-loc Wars, which would not have been a good idea. A man could start some embarrassing rumors that way. "Look," he said. "I know this sounds outrageous, but you have to give it a chance."

ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət hɪm, ən . . . wɑz ʃi kɹaɪɪŋ əɡɛn? wʌt hæɾ i dʌn?

She looked up at him, and . . . was she crying again? What had he done?

"mæt, aɪ kəd kɪs ju," ʃi dɪklɛɹd. "ðɪs ɪz ɪɡzækli wʌɾ aɪ niɾəd!"

"Mat, I could kiss you," she declared. "This is exactly what I needed!"

mæt blɪŋkt. wʌt?

Mat blinked. What?

bɝdʒɪt tʃʌkəld. "fɝs nɔɹi, naʊ mæt. jəl əv tə wɑtʃ jɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn. ɹænd wɪl bi dʒɛləs."

Birgitte chuckled. "First Norry, now Mat. You'll have to watch yourself, Elayne. Rand will be jealous."

ɪleɪn snɔɹɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət ðə plænz. "ðə bɛlfndɝz ɑɹən gɑnə laɪk ðɪs. moʊst ə ðə kɹæfsmən wɝ lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk tə deɪli wɝk, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə sidʒ."

Elayne snorted, looking down at the plans. "The bellfounders aren't going to like this. Most of the craftsmen were looking forward to getting back to daily work, following the siege."

"oʊ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðæt, ɪleɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "aɪv noʊn ə kɹæfsmən əɹ tu ɪn maɪ taɪm.

"Oh, I don't know about that, Elayne," Birgitte said. "I've known a craftsman or two in my time.

tə ə pɝsən, ðeɪ kəmpleɪn əbaʊt ɹɔɪəl pɹɪvlədʒ dʊɹɪŋ wɔɹ, bʌɾ əz lɔŋ əz ðə kɹaʊn kɑmpənseɪts ðɛm, ðəɹ sikɹɪtli hæpi. stɛɾi wɝk ɪz ɔlweɪz əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd. bɪsaɪdz, sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs wɪl meɪk əm kjʊɹiəs."

To a person, they complain about royal privilege during war, but as long as the Crown compensates them, they're secretly happy. Steady work is always appreciated. Besides, something like this will make them curious."

"wil əv tə kip ɪt sikɹət," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"We'll have to keep it secret," Elayne said.

"soʊ jəl də ɪt?" mæt æskt, sɝpɹaɪzd. hi hæd nɑt niɾəd ɪz sikɹət bɹaɪb tə dɪstʃɹæk hɝ!

"So you'll do it?" Mat asked, surprised. He had not needed his secret bribe to distract her!

"wil nid pɹuf ʌv wʌn wɝkɪŋ fɝst, ʌv kɔɹs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪf ðiz dɪvaɪsəz, ðiz dʒɹæɡənz, wɝk hæf əz wɛl əz ɑlʌdʒɹə kleɪmz . .  wɛl, aɪd bi ə ful nɑt tə pʊɾ ɛvɹi mæn ɑn əm wi kæn!"

"We'll need proof of one working first, of course," Elayne said. "But if these devices, these dragons, work half as well as Aludra claims . .  well, I'd be a fool not to put every man on them we can!"

"ðæts ɹaɪt dʒɛnɝəs ə ju," mæt sɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd.

"That's right generous of you," Mat said, scratching his head.

ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "dʒɛnɝəs?"

"bɪldɪŋ ðiz fəɹ ðə bænd."

"hɪɹ naʊ," mæt sɛd. "ðiz ɑɹ maɪ plænz."

"æn maɪ ɹisɔɹsɪz!" ɪleɪn sɛd. ʃi sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, sʌɾənli bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ pɔɪzd. "ʃʊɹli jə si ðət ðə kɹaʊn kəɾ ɔfɝ ə mɔɹ steɪbəl ən jusfəl kəntʃɹoʊl fəɹ ðə dɪplɔɪmən ə ðiz wɛpənz."

"And my resources!" Elayne said. She sat up straight, suddenly becoming more poised. "Surely you see that the Crown could offer a more stable and useful control for the deployment of these weapons."

tə ðə saɪd, θɔɹn wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ.

To the side, Thorn was grinning.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə soʊ hæpi əbaʊt?" mæt dɪmændəd.

"What are you so happy about?" Mat demanded.

"nʌθɪŋ," θɔɹn sɛd. "ju də jəɹ mʌðɝ pɹaʊd, ɪleɪn."

"Nothing," Thorn said. "You do your mother proud, Elayne."

"θæŋk ju, θɔɹn," ʃi sɛd, feɪvɝɪŋ ɪm wɪð ə smaɪl.

"Thank you, Thorn," she said, favoring him with a smile.

"huz saɪɾ ɑɹ jə ɑn?" mæt sɛd.

"ɛvɹiwʌnz," θɔɹn sɛd.

"That's not a bloody side," Mat said, then looked back to Elayne. "I put a lot of effort and thought into getting these plans out of Aludra. I've nothing inst Andor, but I don't trust anyone with these weapons who isn't me."

"æn ɪf ðə bænd wɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ?" ɪleɪn æskt. ʃi ɹɪli dɪd saʊn laɪk ə kwin ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən.

"And if the Band were part of Andor?" Elayne asked. She really did sound like a queen all of a sudden.

"ðə bæn ɪz bɪhoʊldən tə noʊbɑdi," mæt sɛd.

"That is admirable, Mat," Elayne said, "but it makes you mercenaries. I think that the Band deserves something more, something better. With official backing, you would have access to resources and authority. We could give you a commission in Andor, with your own command structure."

ɪt wɑz æktʃəli  tɛmptɪŋ. dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl. bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪleɪn wəd bi hæpi tə hæv ɪm ɪn əɹ ɹɛlm wʌns ʃi nu ʌv ɪz ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ðə sintʃæn. hi mɛn tə ɹɪtɝn tə tuɑn ɪvɛntʃəwəli, sʌmhaʊ. ɪf oʊnli tə wɝk aʊt wʌt ʃi ɹɪli fɛlt əbaʊt hɪm.

It was actually tempting. Just a little. But it did not matter. He did not think Elayne would be happy to have him in her realm once she knew of his relationship with the Seanchan. He meant to return to Tuon eventually, somehow. If only to work out what she really felt about him.

hi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ðə sintʃæn æksɛs tə ðiz dʒɹæɡənz, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt fænsi ɡɪvɪŋ əm tə ændɝ, iðɝ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hi hæd tə ədmɪt ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ hi wɑz gɑnə hæv ændɝ bɪld əm wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ðə wɛpənz tə ðə neɪʃən, tu.

He had no intention of giving the Seanchan access to these dragons, but he did not fancy giving them to Andor, either. Unfortunately, he had to admit that there was no way he was going to have Andor build them without giving the weapons to the nation, too.

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn ə kəmɪʃən fəɹ ðə bænd," mæt sɛd. "wɝ fɹi mɛn, ən ðæts haʊ wi laɪk ɪt."

"I don't want a commission for the Band," Mat said. "We're free men, and that's how we like it."

ɪleɪn lʊk tʃɹʌbəld.

Elayne looked troubled.

"bʌɾ aɪd bi wɪlɪŋ tə splɪt ðə dʒɹæɡənz wɪð ju," mæt sɛd. "sʌm fəɹ ʌs, səm fəɹ ju."

"But I'd be willing to split the dragons with you," Mat said. "Some for us, some for you."

"wʌɾ ɪf" ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪ bɪlt ɔl ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz ən oʊn ɔl ə ðɛm - bʌt pɹɑməs ðəɾ oʊnli ðə bæn kəd juz ðɛm? noʊ ʌðɝ fɔɹsɪz wəɾ əv æksɛs tə ðɛm."

"What if" Elayne said, "I built all of the dragons and owned all of them - but promised that only the Band could use them? No other forces would have access to them."

"ðæt wəd bi kaɪndə ju," mæt sɛd. "səspɪʃəs, ðoʊ. noʊ əfɛns."

"That would be kind of you," Mat said. "Suspicious, though. No offense."

ɪt wəd bi bɛɾɝ fəɹ mi ɪf ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz dɪdn əv ðiz, ət lis nɑɾ ət fɝst. ðəl spɹɛɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli. wɛpənz ɔlweɪz du. aɪ bɪld əm ən pɹɑməs tə ɡɪv əm tə ðə bænd. noʊ kəmɪʃən, dʒʌst ə kɑn- tʃɹækt, haɪɹɪŋ jə fəɹ ə lɔŋ tɝm. jə kən ɡoʊ əɾ ɛni taɪm. bʌɾ ɪf jə du, jə liv ðə dʒɹæɡənz bɪhaɪnd."

It would be better for me if the noble Houses didn't have these, at least not at first. They will spread eventually. Weapons always do. I build them and promise to give them to the Band. No commission, just a con- tract, hiring you for a long term. You can go at any time. But if you do, you leave the dragons behind."

mæt fɹaʊnd. "filz laɪk jəɹ ɹæpɪŋ ə tʃeɪn ɝaʊn maɪ nɛk, ɪleɪn."

Mat frowned. "Feels like you're wrapping a chain around my neck, Elayne."

"aɪm oʊnli sədʒɛstɪŋ ɹizənəbəl səluʃənz."

"I'm only suggesting reasonable solutions."

"ðə deɪ jə bɪkʌm ɹizənəbəl ɪz ðə deɪ aɪ it maɪ hæt," mæt sɛd. "noʊ əfɛns."

"The day you become reasonable is the day I eat my hat," Mat said. "No offense."

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm. jɛs, ʃi hæd bɪkʌm ə kwin. dʒʌs laɪk ðæt.

Elayne raised an eyebrow at him. Yes, she had become a queen. Just like that.

"aɪ wɑn ðə ɹaɪt tə kip ə fju ʌv ðiz dʒɹæɡənz," mæt sɛd, "ɪf wi liv. wʌn-kɔɹɾɝ tə ʌs, θɹi- kɔɹɾɝz tə ju. bʌt wɪl teɪk jəɹ kɑntʃɹækt, ən waɪl wɝ ɪn jəɹ ɛmplɔɪ, oʊnli wi juz ðɛm. əz jə sɛd."

"I want the right to keep a few of these dragons," Mat said, "if we leave. One-quarter to us, three- quarters to you. But we'll take your contract, and while we're in your employ, only we use them. As you said."

hɝ fɹaʊn dipənd. bɝn hɪm, bʌt ʃi; hæd ɡɹæsp ðə paʊɝ ə ðoʊz dʒɹæɡənz kwɪkli. hi kəd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ hɛzəteɪt naʊ. ðeɪ niɾəd ðə dʒɹæɡənz tə ɡoʊ ɪndə pɹədʌkʃən ɪmiɾiətli. ən i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛt ðə tʃæns ə hævɪŋ əm pæs ðə bæn baɪ.

Her frown deepened. Burn him, but she; had grasped the power of those dragons quickly. He could not let her hesitate now. They needed the dragons to go into production immediately. And he was not about to let the chance of having them pass the Band by.

saɪɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, mæt ɹitʃt ʌp ən əndɪd ðə stʃɹæp ət ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk, ðən pʊl ðə fəmɪljɝ fɑkshɛd mədæljən aʊɾ ə hɪz ʃɝt. ðə sɛkən i ɹimuvd ɪt, hi fɛl mɔɹ neɪkəd ðən ɪf i hæd stʃɹɪp bɛɹ. hi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl.

Sighing to himself, Mat reached up and undid the strap at the back of his neck, then pulled the familiar foxhead medallion out of his shirt. The second he removed it, he felt more naked than if he had stripped bare. He set it on the table.

ɪleɪn ɡlænst əɾ ɪt, ən i kəd si ə flæʃ ə dɪzaɪɝ ɪn əɹ aɪz. "wʌɾ ɪz ðət fɔɹ?"

Elayne glanced at it, and he could see a flash of desire in her eyes. "What is that for?"

"ɪts ə swiɾənɝ," mæt sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ɛlboʊz ɑn niz. "ju ɡɛɾ ɪt fəɹ wʌn deɪ ɪf jə əɡɹi tə stɑɹt pɹədʌkʃən ɑn ə pɹoʊɾətaɪp dʒɹæɡən ðɪs ivnɪŋ. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌt jə də wɪð ðə mədæljən - stʌɾi ɪt, ɹaɪɾ ə blʌɾi bʊk əbaʊɾ ɪt, wɛɹ ɪɾ əbaʊt. bʌt jə ɹɪtɝn ɪt təmɑɹoʊ. jəɹ wɝɾ ɑn ɪt."

"It's a sweetener," Mat said, leaning forward, elbows on knees. "You get it for one day if you agree to start production on a prototype dragon this evening. I don't care what you do with the medallion - study it, write a bloody book about it, wear it about. But you return it tomorrow. Your word on it."

bɝdʒɪt wɪsəl sloʊli. ɪleɪn hæd wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðət mədæljən ðə moʊmənt ʃi dɪskʌvɝɾ i hæɾ ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, soʊ hæɾ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət mæt hæd mɛt.

Birgitte whistled slowly. Elayne had wanted to get her hands on that medallion the moment she discovered he had it. Of course, so had every other bloody Aes Sedai that Mat had met.

"aɪ ɡɛt ðə bæn ɪn ət list ə wʌn-jɪɹ kɑntʃɹækt," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ɹinuəbəl. wɪl peɪ jə wʌtɛvɝ jə wɝ ɝnɪŋ ɪn mʊɹændi."

"I get the Band in at least a one-year contract," Elayne said, "renewable. We'll pay you whatever you were earning in Murandy."

haʊ dɪd ʃi noʊ əbaʊt ðæt?

How did she know about that?

"ju kən kænsəl," ʃi kəntɪnjud, "æz lɔŋ əz jə pɹəvaɪɾ ə mʌnθs wɔɹnɪŋ - bʌɾ aɪ kip fɔɹ dʒɹæɡənz aʊɾ ə faɪv. ən ɛni mɛn u wɪʃ tə dʒɔɪn ði ændɔɝən mɪlətɛɹi mʌs bi ɡɪvən ðə tʃæns."

"You can cancel," she continued, "as long as you provide a month's warning - but I keep four dragons out of five. And any men who wish to join the Andoran military must be given the chance."

"aɪ wɑnt wʌn aʊɾ ə fɔɹ," mæt sɛd. "æn ə nu sɝvɪŋ mæn."

"I want one out of four," Mat said. "And a new serving man."

"ə wʌt?" ɪleɪn sɛd.

"A what?" Elayne said.

"ə sɝvɪŋ mæn," mæt sɛd. "ju noʊ, tə teɪk kɛɹ ə maɪ kloʊðɪŋ. jud də ə bɛɾɝ dʒɑb ə pɪkɪŋ ðən aɪ wʊd."

"A serving man," Mat said. "You know, to take care of my clothing. You'd do a better job of picking than I would."

ɪleɪn lʊkt əɾ ɪz koʊt, ðən ʌp əɾ ɪz hɛɹ. "ðæt," ʃi sɛd, "aɪl ɡɪv jə ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə haʊ ði ʌðɝ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz ɡoʊ."

Elayne looked at his coat, then up at his hair. "That," she said, "I'll give you regardless of how the other negotiations go."

"wʌn aʊɾ ə fɔɹ?" mæt sɛd.

"One out of four?" Mat said.

"aɪ ɡɛt ðə mədæljən fəɹ θɹi deɪz."

"I get the medallion for three days."

hi ʃɪvɝd. θɹi deɪz, wɪð ðə ɡoʊləɛn ɪn taʊn. ʃi wəɾ əv ɪm dɛd. ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ə ɡæmbəl tə ɡɪv ɪt tə hɝ fəɹ ə deɪ. bʌɾ i kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls i kəɾ ɔfɝ. "wʌt dʒju ivən θɪŋk jə kən də wɪð ðə θɪŋ?" hi æskt.

He shivered. Three days, with the ghola?n in town. She would have him dead. It was already a gamble to give it to her for a day. But he could not think of anything else he could offer. "What do you even think you can do with the thing?" he asked.

"kɑpi ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛɾ æbsənli, "ɪf aɪm lʌki."

"Copy it," Elayne said absently, "if I'm lucky."

"ɹɪli?"

"Really?"

"aɪ woʊnt noʊ əntɪl aɪ stʌɾi ɪt."

"I won't know until I study it."

mæt sʌɾənli hæd ðə hɔɹəfaɪɪŋ ɪmədʒ ʌv ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə wɝld ɹɪŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz mədæljənz. hi ʃɛɹɾ ə lʊk wɪð θɔɹn, hu simd ikwəli sɝpɹaɪz tə hɪɹ ðɪs.

Mat suddenly had the horrifying image of every Aes Sedai in the world earing one of those medallions. He shared a look with Thorn, who seemed equally surprised to hear this.

bʌt wʌd ðət mæɾɝ? mæt kəd nɑt tʃænəl. bɪfɔɹ, hi hæd wɝid ðət - ɪf ʃi stʌɾid ɪt -  ɪleɪn maɪt fɪɡjɝ ə weɪ tə tʌtʃ ɪm wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ wən i wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ɪt. bʌɾ ɪf ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə kɑpi ɪt wɛl, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɹɪlivd. ən ɪntʃɹiɡd.

But what did that matter? Mat could not channel. Before, he had worried that - if she studied it -  Elayne might figure a way to touch him with the One Power when he was wearing it. But if she just wanted to copy it well, he found himself relieved. And intrigued.

"ðɛɹz bɪn sʌmθɪŋ aɪv bɪn minɪŋ tə mɛnʃən, ɪleɪn," hi sɛd. "ðə ɡoʊləm ɪz hɪɹ. ɪn taʊn. ɪts bɪn kɪlɪŋ pipəl."

"There's been something I've been meaning to mention, Elayne," he said. "The gholam is here. In town. It's been killing people."

ɪleɪn ɹɪmeɪn kɑm, bʌɾ i kəd tɛl fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi wɑz ivən mɔɹ fɔɹməl wən ʃi spoʊk ðət ðə nuz wɝid hɝ. "ðɛn əl bi sɝɾən tə ɹɪtɝn ðə mədæljən tə jə ɑn taɪm."

Elayne remained calm, but he could tell from the way she was even more formal when she spoke that the news worried her. "Then I will be certain to return the medallion to you on time."

hi ɡɹɪməst. "ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd. "θɹi deɪz."

He grimaced. "All right," he said. "Three days."

"vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ wɑn ðə bæn tə stɑɹɾ ɪmiɾiətli. əl bi tʃɹævlɪŋ tə kɛɹhin sun, ən aɪ hæv ə filɪŋ ðeɪ wəd bi ə bɛɾɝ səpɔɹt fɔɹs ðəɹ ðən ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd."

"Very well," she said. "I want the Band to start immediately. I'll be Traveling to Cairhien soon, and I have a feeling they would be a better support force there than the Queen's Guard."

soʊ ðət wɑz wʌt ðɪs wɑz əbaʊt! ɪleɪn wɑz muvɪŋ ɑn ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. wɛl, ðət simd ə ɡʊd jus fəɹ ðə mɛn, ət list əntɪl mæt niɾəd ðɛm. bɛɾɝ ðən lɛɾɪŋ əm sɪɾ ɝaʊnd ɡɛɾɪŋ leɪzi ən pɪkɪŋ faɪts wɪð sɛl-sɔɹdz.

So that was what this was about! Elayne was moving on the Sun Throne. Well, that seemed a good use for the men, at least until Mat needed them. Better than letting them sit around getting lazy and picking fights with sell-swords.

"aɪ əɡɹi tə ðæt," mæt sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪleɪn, ðə bæn əz tə bi fɹi tə faɪɾ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl, haʊɛvɝ ɹænd wɑns. ən ɑlʌdʒɹə hæz tə supɝvaɪz ðə dʒɹæɡənz. aɪ hæv ə filɪŋ ðət ʃɪl ɪnsɪs ðət ʃi ɹɪmeɪn wɪð jə ɪf ðə bæn bɹeɪks ɔf fɹəm ændɝ."

"I agree to that," Mat said, "but Elayne, the Band has to be free to fight in the Last Battle, however Rand wants. And Aludra has to supervise the dragons. I have a feeling that she'll insist that she remain with you if the Band breaks off from Andor."

"aɪ hæv noʊ ɪʃuz wɪð ðæt," ɪleɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ.

"I have no issues with that," Elayne said, smiling.

aɪ fɪɡjɝd jə wʊdnt. bʌt, dʒʌst soʊ wɝ klɪɹ, ðə bæn əz kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz əntɪl wi liv. jə kæn sɛl ðə tɛknɑlədʒi tə ʌðɝz."

I figured you wouldn't. But, just so we're clear, the Band has control of the dragons until we leave. You can't sell the technology to others."

"sʌmwʌn wɪl ɹɛpləkeɪɾ ɪt, mæt," ʃi sɛd.

"Someone will replicate it, Mat," she said.

kɑpiz woʊn bi əz ɡʊɾ əz ɑlʌdʒɹəz," mæt sɛd. "aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðæt."

Copies won't be as good as Aludra's," Mat said. "I promise you that."

ɪleɪn stʌɾid hɪm, blu aɪz weɪɪŋ hɪm, dʒʌdʒɪŋ hɪm. "aɪd stɪl ɹæðɝ əv ðə bæn əz ə fʊli kəmɪʃən ændɔɝən fɔɹs."

Elayne studied him, blue eyes weighing him, judging him. "I'd still rather have the Band as a fully commissioned Andoran force."

"wɛl, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ hæɾ ə hæt meɪɾ ɔl ʌv ɡoʊld, ə tɛn ðət kəd flaɪ ən ə nɔɹs ðət livz dʒɹɑpɪŋz ə daɪmənz. bʌt wɪl boʊθ əv tə sɛɾəl wɪð wʌts ɹizənəbəl, woʊnt wi?"

"Well, I wish I had a hat made all of gold, a tent that could fly and a norse that leaves droppings of diamonds. But we'll both have to settle with what's reasonable, won't we?"

"ɪt wʊdn bi ənɹiznəbəl tə - "

"It wouldn't be unreasonable to - "

"wiɾ əv tə də wʌt jə sɛd, ɪleɪn," mæt ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ woʊn əv ɪt səm bæɾəlz ɑɹənt wɝθ faɪɾɪŋ, ən aɪm gɑnə dɪsaɪd wən maɪ mɛn pʊt ðɛmsɛlvz ət ɹɪsk. ðæts ðæt."

"We'd have to do what you said, Elayne," Mat replied. "I won't have it Some battles aren't worth fighting, and I'm going to decide when my men put themselves at risk. That's that."

"aɪ doʊn laɪk hævɪŋ mɛn u kəd liv mi əɾ ɛni taɪm."

"I don't like having men who could leave me at any time."

"ju noʊ aɪ woʊn hoʊld əm bæk mɪɹli tə spaɪt ju," mæt sɛd. "aɪl də wʌts ɹaɪt."

"You know I won't hold them back merely to spite you," Mat said. "I'll do what's right."

"wʌt jə si əz biɪŋ ɹaɪt," ʃi kɝɛktəd.

"What you see as being right," she corrected.

"ɛvɹi mæn ʃəɾ əv ðəɾ ɑpʃən," hi ɹɪplaɪd, "fju mɛn juz ɪt waɪzli."

"Every man should have that option," he replied, "Few men use it wisely."

"wi wɑn ɪɾ ɛniweɪ," mæt sɛd. "wi dɪmæn ɪt."

"We want it anyway," Mat said. "We demand it."

ʃi ɡlænst - ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɝsɛptɪbli - təwɔɹd ðə plænz ən ðə mədæljən ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "ju hæv ɪt," ʃi sɛd.

She glanced - almost imperceptibly - toward the plans and the medallion on the table. "You have it," she said.

"dil," hi sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp, spɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænd, ən hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt.

"Deal," he said, standing up, spitting in his hand, and holding it out.

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, stʊɾ ən spæɾ ɪn əɹ hænd, ðən hɛld ɪɾ aʊt tə hɪm. hi smaɪld ən ʃʊk ɪt.

She hesitated, stood and spat in her hand, then held it out to him. He smiled and shook it.

"dɪd jə noʊ ðəɾ aɪ maɪɾ æsk jə tə teɪk ɑɹmz əɡɛns ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?" ʃi æskt. "ɪz ðət waɪ jə dɪmændəd ðə ɹaɪt tə liv ɪf jə wɑnt?"

"Did you know that I might ask you to take arms against the Two Rivers?" she asked. "Is that why you demanded the right to leave if you want?"

əɡɛns ðə tu ɹɪvɝz? waɪ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wəd ʃi wɑnə də ðæt? "ju doʊnt nid tə faɪt ðɛm, ɪleɪn."

Against the Two Rivers? Why under the Light would she want to do that? "You don't need to fight them, Elayne."

"wi ʃæl si wʌt pɛɹɪn fɔɹsɪz mi tə du," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "bʌt lɛts nɑt dɪskʌs ðət ɹaɪt naʊ." ʃi ɡlænst ət θɔɹn, ðən ɹitʃt ʌndɝ əɹ teɪbəl ən pʊld aʊɾ ə ɹoʊl pis ə peɪpɝ wɪð ə ɹɪbən əbaʊɾ ɪt. "pliz. aɪ wɑnə hɪɹ mɔɹ ʌv wʌt hæpən dʊɹɪŋ jəɹ tʃɹɪp aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. wɪl jə teɪk dɪnɝ wɪð mi ðɪs ivnɪŋ?"

"We shall see what Perrin forces me to do," she replied. "But let's not discuss that right now." She glanced at Thorn, then reached under her table and pulled out a rolled piece of paper with a ribbon about it. "Please. I want to hear more of what happened during your trip out of Ebou Dar. Will you take dinner with me this evening?"

"wid bi dɪlaɪɾəd," θɔɹn sɛd, stændɪŋ. "wʊdnt wi, mæt?"

"We'd be delighted," Thorn said, standing. "Wouldn't we, Mat?"

"aɪ səpoʊz," mæt sɛd. "ɪf tælmɑnz kən kʌm. hɪl tɛɹ maɪ θɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪf aɪ doʊn ət lis lɛɾ ɪm mit ju, ɪleɪn. teɪkɪŋ dɪnɝ wɪð jəl əv ɪm dænsɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ bæk tə ðə kæmp."

"I suppose," Mat said. "If Talmanes can come. He'll tear my throat out if I don't at least let him meet you, Elayne. Taking dinner with you will have him dancing all the way back to the camp."

ɪleɪn tʃʌkəld. "æz jə wɪʃ. əl əv sɝvəns ʃoʊ jə tə səm ɹumz wɛɹ jə kən ɹɛst əntɪl ðə taɪm ɝaɪvz." ʃi hændəd θɔɹn ðə ɹoʊld-ʌp peɪpɝ. "ðɪs wɪl bi pɹoʊkleɪm təmɑɹoʊ, ɪf jəl ɪt."

Elayne chuckled. "As you wish. I'll have servants show you to some rooms where you can rest until the time arrives." She handed Thorn the rolled-up paper. "This will be proclaimed tomorrow, if you will it."

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" tɑm æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"What is it?" Thom asked, frowning.

"ðə kɔɹɾ ʌv ændɝ læks ə pɹɑpɝ kɔɹt-bɑɹd," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ θɔt jə maɪt bi ɪntʃɹəstəd."

"The court of Andor lacks a proper court-bard," she said. "I thought you might be interested."

tɑm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ju ɑnɝ mi, bʌɾ aɪ kæn æksɛp ðæt. ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz aɪ nid tə də ɪn ðə nɛks lɪɾəl waɪl, ən aɪ kæn bi taɪd tə ðə kɔɹt."

Thom hesitated. "You honor me, but I can't accept that. There are things I need to do in the next little while, and I can't be tied to the court."

"ju nidn bi taɪd tə ðə kɔɹt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "jul əv fɹiɾəm tə liv ən ɡoʊ wɛɹ jə wɪʃ. bʌt wən jə ɑɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, aɪɾ əv jə bi noʊn fəɹ u jə ɑɹ."

"You needn't be tied to the court," Elayne said. "You'll have freedom to leave and go where you wish. But when you are in Caemlyn, I'd have you be known for who you are."

"aɪ..." hi tʊk ðə ɹoʊl ə peɪpɝ. "aɪl kənsɪɾɝ ɪt, ɪleɪn."

"I..." He took the roll of paper. "I'll consider it, Elayne."

"ɛksələnt." ʃi ɡɹɪməst. "aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ hæv ən əpɔɪnmənt wɪð maɪ mɪdwaɪf naʊ, bʌɾ əl si jə ət dɪnɝ. aɪ hævən jɛɾ æskt wʌt meɪtʃɹim mɛn baɪ kɔlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ə mɛɹid mæn ɪn ɪz lɛɾɝ. aɪ ɪkspɛkt ə fʊl ɹipɔɹt! noʊ ɪkspɝɡeɪʃənz!" ʃi aɪd mæt, smaɪlɪŋ slaɪli. "ɪkspɝɡeɪʃən minz 'pɑɹts kʌɾ aʊt,' mæt. ɪn keɪs jə wɝn blʌɾi əwɛɹ."

"Excellent." She grimaced. "I'm afraid I have an appointment with my midwife now, but I will see you at dinner. I haven't yet asked what Matrim meant by calling himself a married man in his letter. I expect a full report! No expurgations!" She eyed Mat, smiling slyly. "Expurgation means 'parts cut out,' Mat. In case you weren't bloody aware."

hi pʊɾ ɪz hæɾ ɑn. "aɪ nu ðæt." wʌt hæd ðət wɝd bɪn əɡɛn? ɛkspɝeɪʃənz? laɪt, waɪ hæɾ i mɛnʃən ɪz mɛɹɪdʒ ɪn ðət lɛɾɝ? hi hæd hoʊpt ɪt wəd meɪk ɪleɪn kjʊɹiəs ɪnʌf tə si hɪm.

He put his hat on. "I knew that." What had that word been again? Expirations? Light, why had he mentioned his marriage in that letter? He had hoped it would make Elayne curious enough to see him.

ɪleɪn læft, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ əm təwɔɹd ði ɛɡzɪt. tɑm spɛɹɾ ə pətɝnəl kɪs fəɹ əɹ tʃik bɪfɔɹ pɑɹɾɪŋ - ɡʊd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz pətɝnəl! mæt hæd hɝd səm θɪŋz əbaʊt ðoʊz tu ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə bɪliv. wɪð tɑm oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi hɝ ɡɹændfɑðɝ, noʊ lɛs.

Elayne laughed, gesturing them toward the exit. Thom spared a paternal kiss for her cheek before parting - good that it was paternal! Mat had heard some things about those two that he did not want to believe. With Thom old enough to be her grandfather, no less.

mæt pʊld oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, muvɪŋ tə liv.

Mat pulled open the door, moving to leave.

"æn mæt," ɪleɪn æɾəd. "ɪf jə nid tə bɑɹoʊ mʌni tə baɪ ə nu koʊt, ðə kɹaʊn kən lɛn jə sʌm. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ jəɹ steɪʃən, jə ɹɪli ʃəd dʒɹɛs mɔɹ naɪsli."

"And Mat," Elayne added. "If you need to borrow money to buy a new coat, the Crown can lend you some. Considering your station, you really should dress more nicely."

"ɪm noʊ blʌɾi noʊbəlmən!" hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ.

"I'm no bloody nobleman!" he said, turning.

"nɑt jɛt," ʃi sɛd. "ju doʊn əv pɛɹɪnz ɑdæsəɾi ɪn neɪmɪŋ jɝsɛlf tə ə taɪɾəl. əl si ðət jə ɡɛt wʌn."

"Not yet," she said. "You don't have Perrin's audacity in naming yourself to a title. I'll see that you get one."

"ju wʊdn dɛɹ," hi sɛd.

"You wouldn't dare," he said.

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"si hɪɹ," hi sɛɾ əz tɑm dʒɔɪn ɪm ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. "aɪm pɹaʊɾ ə hu aɪ æm. ən aɪ laɪk ðɪs koʊt. ɪts kʌmftəɹbəl." hi klɛntʃt ɪz hænz ɪndə fɪsts, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə skɹætʃ əɾ ɪz kɑlɝ.

"See here," he said as Thom joined him in the hallway. "I'm proud of who I am. And I like this coat. It's comfortable." He clenched his hands into fists, refusing to scratch at his collar.

"ɪf jə seɪ soʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɪl si jə ət dɪnɝ. əl əv tə bɹɪŋ daɪɛlɪn. ʃiz vɛɹi kjʊɹiəs tə mit ju."

"If you say so," Elayne said. "I will see you at dinner. I'll have to bring Dyelin. She's very curious to meet you."

wɪð ðæt, ʃi hæd bɝdʒɪt kloʊz ðə dɔɹ. mæt stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt vɛnɡfəli fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən tɝn təwɔɹd tɑm. tælmɑnz ən ðə soʊlʒɝz weɪɾəd ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ, aʊɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ ɹeɪnʒ. ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ ɡɪvən wɔɹm ti baɪ səm pæləs sɝvəns.

With that, she had Birgitte close the door. Mat stared at it vengefully for a moment, then turned toward Thom. Talmanes and the soldiers waited a short distance down the hallway, out of hearing range. They were being given warm tea by some palace servants.

ðət wɛnt wɛl," mæt dɪsaɪɾɪd, hænz ɑn hɪps. "aɪ wɝid ʃi wʊdn baɪt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ ɹild əɹ ɪn pɹɪɾi wɛl." ðoʊ ðə blʌɾi daɪs wɝ stɪl ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd.

That went well," Mat decided, hands on hips. "I worried she wouldn't bite, but I think I reeled her in pretty well." Though the bloody dice were still rolling in his head.

tɑm læft, klæpɪŋ ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ.

Thom laughed, clapping him on the shoulder.

"wʌt?" mæt dɪmændəd.

"What?" Mat demanded.

tɑm dʒʌs tʃʌkəld, ðən ɡlæns daʊn ət ðə skɹoʊl ɪn ɪz ʌðɝ hænd. "æn ðɪs wɑz ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ əz wɛl."

Tom just chuckled, then glanced down at the scroll in his other hand. "And this was unexpected as well."

"wɛl, ændɝ dʌzn əv ə kɔɹt-bɑɹd," mæt sɛd.

"Well, Andor doesn't have a court-bard," Mat said.

"jɛs," θɔɹn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə skɹoʊl. "bʌt ðɛɹz ə pɑɹɾən ɹɪɾən ɪn hɪɹ tu, fəɹ ɛni ən ɔl kɹaɪmz - noʊn ən ənnoʊn - aɪ meɪ hæv kəmɪɾəd ɪn ændɝ əɹ kɛɹhin. aɪ wʌndɝ u toʊl hɝ. . . ."

"Yes," Thorn said, looking over the scroll. "But there's a pardon written in here too, for any and all crimes - known and unknown - I may have committed in Andor or Cairhien. I wonder who told her. . . ."

"toʊld əɹ wʌt?"

"Told her what?"

"nʌθɪŋ, mæt. nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. wɪv ə fju aʊɝz əntɪl dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪn. wʌt dʒju seɪ wi ɡoʊ baɪ jə ə nu koʊt?"

"Nothing, Mat. Nothing at all. We have a few hours until dinner with Elayne. What do you say we go buy you a new coat?"

"ɔl ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd. "ju θɪŋk aɪ kəd ɡɛt wʌn ə ðoʊz pɑɹɾənz, tu ɪf aɪ æsk fəɹ ɪt?"

"All right," Mat said. "You think I could get one of those pardons, too if I asked for it?"

"du jə nid wʌn?"

"Do you need one?"

mæt ʃɹʌɡd, wɔkɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ wɪð hɪm. "kæn hɝt tə bi seɪf. wʌt kaɪndə koʊɾ ɑɹ jə gɑnə baɪ mi, ɛniweɪ?"

Mat shrugged, walking down the hallway with him. "Can't hurt to be safe. What kind of coat are you going to buy me, anyway?"

"aɪ dɪdn seɪ aɪd peɪ."

"I didn't say I'd pay."

"doʊn bi soʊ stɪnʒi," mæt sɛd. "aɪl peɪ fəɹ dɪnɝ." ən blʌɾi æʃəz, sʌmhaʊ, mæt nu, hi wʊd.

A Choice

"ju mʌs nɑt spik," ɹɑsɪl sɛd tə nɪneɪiv. ðə slɛndɝ, lɔŋnɛkt wʊmən wɔɹ ən ɔɹənʒ dʒɹɛs slæʃt wɪð jɛloʊ. "æt list, spik oʊnli wən spoʊkən tə. jə noʊ ðə sɛɹəmoʊni?"

"You must not speak," Rosil said to Nynaeve. The slender, longnecked woman wore an orange dress slashed with yellow. "At least, speak only when spoken to. You know the ceremony?"

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd, hɝ hɑɹt biɾɪŋ tʃɹɛtʃɝəsli əz ðeɪ wɔkt ɪndə ðə dʌndʒɑnlaɪk dɛpθs ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɹɑsɪl wɑz ðə nu mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, ən ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ baɪ koʊɪnsɪɾəns.

She would not give in on that point.

ɹɑsɪl pɝst əɹ lɪps, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ fɝðɝ. ðə wʊmən hæd ʃoʊn nɪneɪiv ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl kaɪndnəs dʊɹɪŋ əɹ ʃɔɹt taɪm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ -  wɪtʃ hæd bɪn ə ɹɪlif. nɪneɪiv hæd ɡɹoʊn tə ɪkspɛk ðəɾ ɛvɹi jɛloʊ sɪstɝ wəd ɹəɡɑɹɾ əɹ wɪð dɪsdeɪn, əɹ ət list ɪndɪfɝəns. oʊ, ðeɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz tæləntəd, ən mɛni ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn biɪŋ tʃɹeɪn baɪ hɝ. bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə hɝ əz wʌn ə ðɛm. nɑt jɛt.

Rosil pursed her lips, but said nothing further. The woman had shown Nynaeve remarkable kindness during her short time in the White Tower -  which had been a relief. Nynaeve had grown to expect that every Yellow sister would regard her with disdain, or at least indifference. Oh, they thought she was talented, and many insisted on being trained by her. But they did not think of her as one of them. Not yet.

ðɪs wʊmən wɑz dɪfɹənt, ən biɪŋ ə bɝ ɪn əɹ sændəl wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡʊd ɹipeɪmənt. "ɪɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə mi, ɹɑsɪl," nɪneɪiv ɪkspleɪnd, "ðæt wʌn nɑt ɡɪv ɛni ɪndəkeɪʃən ə dɪsɹɪspɛk fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn. ʃi neɪmd mi ɛɛs sədaɪ. tə ækt əz ɪf aɪ wɝ mɪɹli æksɛptɪd wəd bi tə ʌndɝmaɪn əɹ wɝdz. ðɪs tɛst ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt - wən ði æmɪɝlɪn ɹeɪz mi, ʃi nɛvɝ sɛd ðəɾ aɪ nid nɑt bi tɛstəd.

This woman was different, and being a burr in her sandal was not a good repayment. "It is important to me, Rosil," Nynaeve explained, "that 1 not give any indication of disrespect for the Amyrlin. She named me Aes Sedai. To act as if I were merely Accepted would be to undermine her words. This test is important - when the Amyrlin raised me, she never said that I need not be tested.

bʌɾ aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ."

But I am Aes Sedai."

nɪneɪiv smaɪld.

Nynaeve smiled.

"naʊ," ɹɑsɪl sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ. "ju maɪt bi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ði aɪz ə ði æmɪɝlɪn ən ðə taʊɝ, bʌt tʃɹədɪʃən stɪl hoʊlz. noʊ spikɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sɛɹəmoʊni, pliz."

The lanky woman continued leading the way. Nynaeve followed, biting off a retort. She wouldn't let her nerves rule her.

dipɝ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ ðeɪ waʊnd, ən dɪspaɪɾ əɹ dɪtɝməneɪʃən tə bi kɑm, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ɪnkɹisɪŋli nɝvəs. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ʃi wəd pæs ðɪs tɛst. ʃid mæstɝd ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz. ʃi dɪdnt nid tə wɝi.

Deeper into the Tower they wound, and despite her determination to be calm, she found herself increasingly nervous. She was Aes Sedai, and she would pass this test. She'd mastered the hundred weaves. She didn't need to worry.

ɪksɛpt, səm wɪmən nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə tɛst.

Except, some women never returned from the test.

ðiz sɛlɝz hæɾ ə ɡɹæn bjuɾi tə ðɛm. ðə smuð stoʊn flɔɹ wɑz lɛvəl kɛɹfəli. læmps bɝn haɪ ɑn ðə wɔlz; laɪkli, ðoʊz hæd ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə sɪstɝ əɹ æksɛptɪd tə laɪɾ əm wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. fju pipəl keɪm daʊn hɪɹ, ən moʊst ə ðə ɹumz wɝ juz fəɹ stɔɹədʒ. ɪt simd ə weɪs tə hɝ tə pʊt sətʃ kɛɹ ɪn ə pleɪs ɹɛɹli vɪzəɾəd.

These cellars had a grand beauty to them. The smooth stone floor was leveled carefully. This is here to show Accepted the importance of what they are about to do.

To show that she had been right in raising Nynaeve.

Saerin embraced the source and wove a weave of Spirit. Nynaeve suppressed the urge to embrace the Source herself.
