"ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt mʌs bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd."

"Remember what must be remembered."

"wʌn hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz jəl wiv, ɪn ði ɔɹɾɝ ðət juv bɪn ɡɪvən ən ɪn pɝfəkt kəmpoʊʒɝ."

"One hundred times you will weave, in the order that you have been given and in perfect composure."

"ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt mʌs bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd," sɹɪn sɛd wʌn faɪnəl taɪm.

"Remember what must be remembered," Saerin said one final time.

nɪneɪiv fɛl ðə wivɪŋ ə spɪɹət sɛɾəl ɪndə hɝ. ɪt wɑz ɹæðɝ laɪk hilɪŋ. ʃi ɹimuvd əɹ dʒɹɛs ən ʃɪft əz ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz nɛl bɪsaɪd ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, pɝfɔɹmɪŋ kɑmplɛks wivz ʌv ɔl faɪv paʊɝz. ðeɪ kɑzd ɪt tə ɡloʊ bɹaɪtli, ðə kʌlɝz ɑn ɪts sɝfəs ʃɪftɪŋ ən tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ɹɑsɪl klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt, ən nɪneɪiv blʌʃt, hændɪŋ əɹ ðə paɪl ʌv ɡɑɹməns, ðən tʊk ɔf əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ən pleɪst ɪɾ ɑn tɑp, fɑloʊd baɪ lænz ɹɪŋ - wɪtʃ ʃi nɔɹməli wɔɹ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk.

Nynaeve felt the weaving of Spirit settle into her. It was rather like Healing. She removed her dress and shift as the other sisters knelt beside the ter'angreal, performing complex weaves of all Five Powers. They caused it to glow brightly, the colors on its surface shifting and changing. Rosil cleared her throat, and Nynaeve blushed, handing her the pile of garments, then took off her Great Serpent ring and placed it on top, followed by Lan's ring - which she normally wore around her neck.

ɹɑsɪl tʊk ðə kloʊðɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɝ kəmplitli əbzɔɹbd ɪn ðɛɹ wɝk. ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil bɪɡæn ɡloʊɪŋ ə pjʊɹ waɪɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, ðən stɑɹɾəd tə ɹivɑlv sloʊli, ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əɡɛns ðə stoʊn.

Rosil took the clothing. The other sisters were completely absorbed in their work. The ter'angreal began glowing a pure white in the center, then started to revolve slowly, grinding against the stone.

nɪneɪiv tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ʃi pɔz bɪfɔɹ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, stɛp θɹu ən . . .

Nynaeve took a deep breath, striding forward. She paused before the ter'angreal, stepped through and . . .

. . . ən wɛɹ wɑz ʃi? nɪneɪiv fɹaʊnd. ðɪs dɪdn lʊk laɪk ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ə vɪlədʒ meɪɾ ə hʌts. weɪvz læpt əɡɛnst ə sændi bitʃ tə hɝ lɛft, ən ðə vɪlədʒ ɹæn ʌp ə sloʊp təwɔɹɾ ə ɹɑki ʃɛlf tə hɝ ɹaɪt. ə dɪstən maʊntən taʊɝɾ əbʌv.

. . . and where was she? Nynaeve frowned. This didn't look like the Two Rivers. She stood in a village made of huts. Waves lapped against a sandy beach to her left, and the village ran up a slope toward a rocky shelf to her right. A distant mountain towered above.

ən aɪlən ə səm sɔɹt. ði ɛɹ wɑz hjuməd, ðə bɹiz kɑm. pipəl wɔk bɪtwin hʌts, kɔlɪŋ ɡʊd-neɪtʃɝdli tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. ə fju stɑp tə stɛɹ ət hɝ. ʃi lʊk daʊn ət hɝsɛlf, ɹilaɪzɪŋ fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðət ʃi wɑz neɪkəd. ʃi blʌʃt fjʊɹiəsli. hu hæd teɪkən əɹ kloʊðɪŋ? wən ʃi faʊn ðə pɝsən ɹispɑnsəbəl ʃid swɪtʃ əm soʊ saʊnli, ðeɪ wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə sɪt fəɹ wiks!

An island of some sort. The air was humid, the breeze calm. People walked between huts, calling good-naturedly to one another. A few stopped to stare at her. She looked down at herself, realizing for the first time that she was naked. She blushed furiously. Who had taken her clothing? When she found the person responsible she'd switch them so soundly, they wouldn't be able to sit for weeks!

ə ɹoʊb wɑz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ kloʊðəzlaɪn. ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ɹɪmeɪn kɑm əz ʃi wɔkt oʊvɝ ən pʊld ɪt fɹi. ʃi wəd faɪn ɪts oʊnɝ ən peɪ ðɛm. ʃi kʊdn vɛɹi wɛl wɔk əbaʊt wɪθaʊɾ ə stɪtʃ. ʃi θɹu ðə ɹoʊb ɑn oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd.

A robe was hanging from a nearby clothesline. She forced herself to remain calm as she walked over and pulled it free. She would find its owner and pay them. She couldn't very well walk about without a stitch. She threw the robe on over her head.

ðə ɡɹaʊnd ʃʊk, sʌɾənli. ðə dʒɛntəl weɪvz ɡɹu laʊɾɝ, kɹæʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðə bitʃ. nɪneɪiv ɡæspt, stɛɾiɪŋ hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðə kloʊðəzlaɪn poʊl. əbʌv, ðə maʊntən bɪɡæn spɝɾɪŋ smoʊk ən æʃəz.

The ground shook, suddenly. The gentle waves grew louder, crashing against the beach. Nynaeve gasped, steadying herself against the clothesline pole. Above, the mountain began spurting smoke and ashes.

nɪneɪiv klʌtʃt ðə poʊl əz ðə ɹɑki ʃɛlf nɪɹbaɪ bɪɡæn tə bɹeɪk əpɑɹt, boʊldɝz tʌmbəlɪŋ daʊn ði ɪnklaɪn. pipəl jɛld. ʃi hæd tə də sʌmθɪŋ! əz ʃi lʊkt əbaʊt, ʃi sɔ ə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ kɑɹvd ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹʌn fəɹ ɪt, bʌt ʃi nu ʃi niɾəd tə wɔk kɛɹfəli.

Nynaeve clutched the pole as the rocky shelf nearby began to break apart, boulders tumbling down the incline. People yelled. She had to do something! As she looked about, she saw a six-pointed star carved into the ground. She wanted to run for it, but she knew she needed to walk carefully.

kipɪŋ kɑm wɑz dɪfəkəlt. əz ʃi wɔkt, hɝ hɑɹt flʌɾɝd wɪð ɹɔɝ. ʃi wɑz gɑnə bi kɹʌʃt! ʃi ɹitʃt ðə stɑɹ pæɾɝn dʒʌst əz ə lɑɹdʒ ʃaʊɝ ə stoʊnz ɹʌmbəl təwɔɹd hɝ, smæʃɪŋ hʌts. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ fɪɹ nɪneɪiv kwɪkli fɔɹm ðə kɝɛkt wiv - ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ ðət fɔɹmd ə wɔl. ʃi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝsɛlf, ən ðə stoʊnz θʌddɪɾ əɡɛns ði ɛɹ, fɔɹs bæk.

Keeping calm was difficult. As she walked, her heart fluttered with rror. She was going to be crushed! She reached the star pattern just as a large shower of stones rumbled toward her, smashing huts. Despite her fear Nynaeve quickly formed the correct weave - a weave of Air that formed a wall. She set it in front of herself, and the stones thudded against the air, forced back.

ðəɹ wɝ hɝt pipəl ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. ʃi tɝn fɹəm ðə stɑɹ pæɾɝn tə hɛlp, bʌɾ əz ʃi dɪd, ʃi sɔ ðə seɪm sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ woʊvən ɪn ɹidz ən hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ ʌv ə nɪɹbaɪ hʌt. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

There were hurt people in the village. She turned from the star pattern to help, but as she did, she saw the same six-pointed star woven in reeds and hanging from the door of a nearby hut. She hesitated.

ʃi kəd nɑt feɪl. ʃi wɔk tə ðə hʌɾ ən pæs θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ.

She could not fail. She walked to the hut and passed through the doorway.

ðən ʃi fɹoʊz. wʌt wɑz ʃi duɪŋ ɪn ðɪs dɑɹk, koʊl kævɝn? ən waɪ wɑz ʃi wɛɹɪŋ ðɪs ɹoʊb ə θɪk, skɹætʃi faɪbɝz?

Then she froze. What was she doing in this dark, cold cavern? And why was she wearing this robe of thick, scratchy fibers?

ʃi hæd kəmpliɾəd ðə fɝst ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz. ʃi nu ðɪs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls. fɹaʊnɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, ʃi wɔk θɹu ðə kævɝn. laɪt ʃoʊn θɹu kɹæks ɪn ðə silɪŋ, ən ʃi sɔ ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pul ʌv ɪɾ əhɛd. ðə weɪ aʊt.

She had completed the first of the hundred weaves. She knew this, but nothing else. Frowning to herself, she walked through the cavern. Light shone through cracks in the ceiling, and she saw a greater pool of it ahead. The way out.

ʃi wɔk fɹəm ðə kævɝn tə faɪn ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə weɪst. ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə ʃeɪɾ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə bɹaɪt sʌnlaɪt. ðəɹ wɑzn ə soʊl ɪn saɪt. ʃi wɔk fɔɹwɝd, fit kɹʌntʃɪŋ ɑn widz ən skɔldɪd baɪ hɑt stoʊnz.

She walked from the cavern to find that she was in the Waste. She raised a hand to shade her eyes from the bright sunlight. There wasn't a soul in sight. She walked forward, feet crunching on weeds and scalded by hot stones.

ðə hit wɑz oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ. sun itʃ stɛp wɑz ɪɡzɔstɪŋ. fɔɹtʃənətli, səm ɹuənz leɪ əhɛd.

The heat was overwhelming. Soon each step was exhausting. Fortunately, some ruins lay ahead.

ʃeɪd! ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹʌn fəɹ ɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn kɑm. ʃi wɔkt ʌp tə ðə stoʊnz, ən əɹ fit fɛl ɑn ɹɑk ʃeɪɾɪd baɪ ə bɹoʊkən wɔl. ɪt wɑz soʊ kul, ʃi saɪɾ ɪn ɹɪlif.

Shade! She wanted to run for it, but she had to remain calm. She walked up to the stones, and her feet fell on rock shaded by a broken wall. It was so cool, she sighed in relief.

ə pæɾɝn ə bɹɪks leɪ nɪɹbaɪ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ðeɪ meɪɾ ə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðət stɑɹ wɑz bæk aʊɾ ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt. ʃi ɹɪlʌktənli lɛf ðə ʃeɪɾ ən wɔk təwɔɹd ðə pæɾɝn.

A pattern of bricks lay nearby in the ground, and they made a six-pointed star. Unfortunately, that star was back out in the sunlight. She reluctantly left the shade and walked toward the pattern.

dʒɹʌmz θʌmpt ɪn ðə dɪstəns. nɪneɪiv spʌn. dɪsɡʌstɪŋ bɹaʊn-fɝd kɹitʃɝz bɪɡæn tə klaɪm oʊvɝ ə nɪɹbaɪ hɪl, kæɹiɪŋ æksiz ðət dʒɹɪpt wɪð ɹɛd blʌd. ðə tʃɹɑləks lʊkt ɹɔŋ tə hɝ.

Drums thumped in the distance. Nynaeve spun. Disgusting brown-furred creatures began to climb over a nearby hill, carrying axes that dripped with red blood. The Trollocs looked wrong to her.

ʃid sin tʃɹɑləks bɪfɔɹ, ðoʊ ʃi dɪdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɛɹ. ðiz wɝ dɪfɹənt. ə nu bɹid, pɝhæps? wɪð θɪkɝ fɝ, aɪz hɪɾən ɪn ðə ɹisɛsəz ə ðɛɹ feɪsəz.

She'd seen Trollocs before, though she didn't remember where. These were different. A new breed, perhaps? With thicker fur, eyes hidden in the recesses of their faces.

nɪneɪiv wɔk fæstɝ, bʌt dɪd nɑt bɹeɪk ɪndə ə ɹʌn. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə kip əɹ kɑm. ðət wɑz kəmplitli stupəd. waɪ wəd ʃi nid tə - əɹ wɑnə - kip hɝsɛlf fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ wən ðəɹ wɝ tʃɹɑləks nɪɹbaɪ? ɪf ʃi daɪd kəz ʃi wɑznt wɪlɪŋ tə heɪsən əɹ stɛp, ɪt wəd bi hɝ oʊn fɔlt.

Nynaeve walked faster, but did not break into a run. It was important to keep her calm. That was completely stupid. Why would she need to - or want to - keep herself from running when there were Trollocs nearby? If she died because she wasn't willing to hasten her step, it would be her own fault.

kip kəmpoʊʒɝ. doʊn muv tu kwɪkli.

Keep composure. Don't move too quickly.

ʃi meɪnteɪn əɹ stɛɾi peɪs, ɹitʃɪŋ ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ əz ðə tʃɹɑləks dʒɹu kloʊs. ʃi bɪɡæn ðə wiv ʃi wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə meɪk ən splɪɾ ɔf ə θɹɛɾ ə faɪɝ. ʃi sɛn ən ɪnɔɹməs spɹeɪ ʌv hiɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, bɝnɪŋ ðə nɪɹəst ə ðə bists tə sɪndɝz.

She maintained her steady pace, reaching the six-pointed star as the Trollocs drew close. She began the weave she was required to make and split off a thread of Fire. She sent an enormous spray of heat away from her, burning the nearest of the beasts to cinders.

dʒɔ sɛɾ əɡɛnst əɹ fɪɹ, ʃi kɹæftɪd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹikwaɪɝd wiv. ʃi splɪɾ əɹ wivz ə hæf- dʌzən taɪmz ən fɪnɪʃt ðə kɑmpləkeɪɾəd θɪŋ ɪn mɪɹ moʊməns.

Jaw set against her fear, she crafted the rest of the required weave. She split her weaves a half- dozen times and finished the complicated thing in mere moments.

ʃi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn pleɪs, ðən nɑɾəd. ðɛɹ. ʌðɝ tʃɹɑləks wɝ kʌmɪŋ ən ʃi bɝn əm əweɪ wɪð ə weɪv ə hɝ hænd.

She set it in place, then nodded. There. Other Trollocs were coming and she burned them away with a wave of her hand.

ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ wɑz kɑɹvd ɪndə ðə saɪɾ ʌv ən ɑɹtʃweɪ ʌv stoʊn. ʃi wɔk təwɔɹɾ ɪt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip fɹəm lʊkɪŋ nɝvəsli oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks wɝ kʌmɪŋ. mɔɹ ðən ʃi kəd pɑsəbli kɪl.

The six-pointed star was carved into the side of an archway of stone. She walked toward it, trying to keep from looking nervously over her shoulder. More Trollocs were coming. More than she could possibly kill.

ʃi ɹitʃt ði ɑɹtʃweɪ ən stɛp θɹu.

She reached the archway and stepped through.

nɪneɪiv fɪnɪʃt ðə fɔɹɾi-sɛvənθ wiv, wɪtʃ kɑz ðə saʊnz ə bɛlz ɪn ði ɛɹ. ʃi wɑz ɪɡzɔstəd. ʃid hæd tə meɪk ðɪs wiv waɪl stændɪŋ ɑn tɑp ʌv ən ɪmpɑsəbli nɛɹoʊ taʊɝ hʌnʒɹədz ə fiɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ. wɪn bəfeɪd hɝ, θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə bloʊ hɝ fɹi.

Nynaeve finished the forty-seventh weave, which caused the sounds of bells in the air. She was exhausted. She'd had to make this weave while standing on top of an impossibly narrow tower hundreds of feet in the air. Wind buffeted her, threatening to blow her free.

ən ɑɹtʃweɪ əpɪɹd bɪloʊ, ɪn ðə dɑɹk naɪɾ ɛɹ. ɪt sim tə ɡɹoʊ ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə pɪlɝz saɪɾ ə dʌzən fit bɪloʊ hɝ, pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɪts oʊpənɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ. ɪt hɛl ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ.

An archway appeared below, in the dark night air. It seemed to grow right out of the pillar's side a dozen feet below her, parallel to the ground, its opening toward the sky. It held the six-pointed star.

ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ʃi lɛpt ɔf ðə spaɪɹ ən fɛl θɹu ði ɑɹtʃweɪ.

Gritting her teeth, she leaped off the spire and fell through the archway.

ʃi lændəɾ ɪn ə pʌɾəl. hɝ kloʊðɪŋ wɑz ɡɔn. wʌt hæd hæpən tə ɪt? ʃi stʊɾ ʌp, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ waɪ, bʌt sʌmwʌn hæd dʌn . . . sʌmθɪŋ tə hɝ.

She landed in a puddle. Her clothing was gone. What had happened to it? She stood up, growling to herself. She was angry. She didn't know why, but someone had done . . . something to her.

ʃi wɑz soʊ taɪɝd. ðət wɑz ðɛɹ fɔlt, huɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ. əz ʃi foʊkəst ɑn ðət θɔt, ɪt bɪkeɪm mɔɹ klɪɹ tə hɝ. ʃi kʊdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt ðeɪd dʌn, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ dɛfənətli tə bleɪm.

She was so tired. That was their fault, whoever they were. As she focused on that thought, it became more clear to her. She couldn't remember what they'd done, but they were definitely to blame.

ʃi hæd kʌts əkɹɔs boʊθ ə hɝ ɑɹmz. hæd ʃi bɪn wɪpt? ðə kʌts hɝt sʌmθɪŋ fɪɹs.

She had cuts across both of her arms. Had she been whipped? The cuts hurt something fierce.

dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɛt, ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊnd. ʃid kəmpliɾəd fɔɹɾi-sɛvən ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz. ʃi nu ðæt, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls. ʌðɝ ðən ðə fæk ðət sʌmbɑɾi vɛɹi bædli wɑntəɾ əɹ tə feɪl.

Dripping wet, she looked around. She'd completed forty-seven of the hundred weaves. She knew that, but nothing else. Other than the fact that somebody very badly wanted her to fail.

ʃi wɑzn gɑnə lɛɾ əm wɪn. ʃi ɹoʊz aʊɾ ə ðə pʌɾəl, dɪtɝmən tə bi kɑm, ən faʊn səm kloʊðɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ. ɪt wɑz ɡɛɹɪʃli kʌlɝd, bɹaɪt pɪŋk ən jɛloʊ wɪð ə dʒɛnɝəs hɛlpɪŋ ə ɹɛd.

She wasn't going to let them win. She rose out of the puddle, determined to be calm, and found some clothing nearby. It was garishly colored, bright pink and yellow with a generous helping of red.

ɪt simd ən ɪnsəlt. ʃi pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn ɛniweɪ.

It seemed an insult. She put it on anyway.

ʃi wɔk daʊn ə pæθ ɪn ðə bɑɡ, stɛpɪŋ ɝaʊn sɪŋkhoʊlz ən pulz ə stæɡnənt wɔɾɝ, əntɪl ʃi faʊn ə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ dʒɹɔn ɪn ðə mʌd. ʃi bɪɡæn ðə nɛkst wiv, wɪtʃ wəd meɪk ə bɝnɪŋ blu stɑɹ ʃuɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

She walked down a path in the bog, stepping around sinkholes and pools of stagnant water, until she found a six-pointed star drawn in the mud. She began the next weave, which would make a burning blue star shoot into the air.

sʌmθɪŋ bɪɾ əɾ əɹ nɛk. ʃi slæpt əɹ hæn əɾ ɪt, kɪlɪŋ ə blæk-flaɪ. wɛl, noʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðət ʃid faɪn ðoʊz ɪn ðɪs dæŋk swɑmp. ʃi wəd bi ɡlæd tə -  ənʌðɝ baɪɾ ɑn əɹ ɑɹm. ʃi slæpt əɾ ɪt. ðə vɛɹi ɛɹ stɑɹɾəd tə bʌz, flaɪz zɪpɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ.

Something bit at her neck. She slapped her hand at it, killing a black-fly. Well, no surprise that she'd find those in this dank swamp. She would be glad to -  Another bite on her arm. She slapped at it. The very air started to buzz, flies zipping around her.

nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, kəntɪnjuɪŋ ðə wiv. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ baɪts pɹɪkəld ɑn əɹ ɑɹmz. ʃi kʊdn kɪl əm ɔl. kəd ʃi ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə flaɪz wɪð ə wiv? ʃi bɪɡæn ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ tə kɹieɪɾ ə bɹiz ɝaʊn hɝ, bʌt wɑz ɪntɝʌptɪɾ əz ʃi hɝd skɹimz.

Nynaeve gritted her teeth, continuing the weave. More and more bites prickled on her arms. She couldn't kill them all. Could she get rid of the flies with a weave? She began a weave of Air to create a breeze around her, but was interrupted as she heard screams.

ɪt wɑz feɪn oʊvɝ ðə bʌzɪŋ ə ðə flaɪz, bʌɾ ɪt saʊndəd laɪk ə tʃaɪl tʃɹæpt ɪn ðə bɑɡ! nɪneɪiv tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd ðə saʊnz ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə kɔl, bʌt blækfliz swɔɹmd ɪndə hɝ maʊθ, tʃoʊkɪŋ hɝ. ðeɪ ɡɑɾ əɾ əɹ aɪz, ən ʃi hæd tə skwiz əm ʃʌt.

It was faint over the buzzing of the flies, but it sounded like a child trapped in the bog! Nynaeve took a step toward the sounds and opened her mouth to call, but blackflies swarmed into her mouth, choking her. They got at her eyes, and she had to squeeze them shut.

ðət bʌzɪŋ. ðə skɹimz. ðə baɪɾɪŋ. laɪt, ðeɪ wɝ ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt! ɪn əɹ lʌŋz!

That buzzing. The screams. The biting. Light, they were in her throat! In her lungs!

fɪnɪʃ ðə wiv. jə mʌs fɪnɪʃ ðə wiv.

Finish the weave. You must finish the weave.

ʃi kəntɪnjud, sʌmhaʊ, dɪspaɪt ðə peɪn. ðə saʊn ə ði ɪnsɛks wɑz soʊ laʊd ðət ʃi kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ ðə wuʃ ə ðə faɪɝi stɑɹ əz ɪt blæstəɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ʃi kwɪkli woʊv ə wiv tə bloʊ ðə flaɪz əweɪ, ən wʌns ʃi dɪd, ʃi lʊkt əbaʊt. ʃi kɔft ən tʃɹɛmbəld. ʃi kəd fil ðə flaɪz stɪkɪŋ tə ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɝ θɹoʊt. ʃi dɪdn si ɛni tʃaɪld ɪn deɪnʒɝ. hæɾ ɪt bɪn ə tʃɹɪk ə hɝ ɪɹz?

She continued, somehow, despite the pain. The sound of the insects was so loud that she could barely hear the whoosh of the fiery star as it blasted into the air. She quickly wove a weave to blow the flies away, and once she did, she looked about. She coughed and trembled. She could feel the flies sticking to the inside of her throat. She didn't see any child in danger. Had it been a trick of her ears?

ʃi dɪd si ənʌðɝ sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ, əbʌv ə dɔɹ kɑɹvd ɪndə ə tʃɹi. ʃi wɔk təwɔɹɾ ɪɾ əz ðə flaɪz bʌzd ɝaʊn əɹ əɡɛn. kɑm. ʃi hæd tə bi kɑm! waɪ? ɪt meɪd noʊ sɛns! ʃi dɪɾ ɪɾ ɛniweɪ, wɔkɪŋ wɪð aɪz kloʊzd əz ðə flaɪz swɔɹm hɝ. ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt, filɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɔɹ ən pʊlɪŋ ɪɾ oʊpən. ʃi stɛp θɹu.

She did see another six-pointed star, above a door carved into a tree. She walked toward it as the flies buzzed around her again. Calm. She had to be calm! Why? It made no sense! She did it anyway, walking with eyes closed as the flies swarmed her. She reached out, feeling for the door and pulling it open. She stepped through.

ʃi pʊl tə ə stɑp ɪnsaɪd ðə bɪldɪŋ, wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ʃi wɑz kɑfɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ. wɑz ʃi ɪl?

She pulled to a stop inside the building, wondering why she was coughing so much. Was she ill?

ʃi lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ɪɡzɔstəd, æŋɡɹi. hɝ iɛɡz wɝ kʌvɝɾ ɪn skɹeɪps, ən əɹ ɑɹmz ɪtʃt wɪð səm kaɪndə ɪnsɛk baɪts. ʃi ɡɹoʊnd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ əɹ ɡɛɹɪʃ kloʊðɪŋ. wʌt kəd pɑsəbli hæv pəzɛst əɹ tə wɛɹ ɹɛd, jɛloʊ ən pɪŋk təɡɛðɝ?

She leaned against the wall, exhausted, angry. Her iegs were covered in scrapes, and her arms itched with some kind of insect bites. She groaned, looking down at her garish clothing. What could possibly have possessed her to wear red, yellow and pink together?

ʃi stʊɾ ʌp wɪð ə saɪ ən kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə ɹɪkəɾi hɔlweɪ. ðə plæŋks ðət meɪɾ ʌp ðə flɔɹ ɹæɾəld əz ʃi wɔkt, ən ðə plæstɝ ɑn ðə wɔlz wɑz bɹoʊkən ən kɹʌmbəlɪŋ.

She stood up with a sigh and continued down the rickety hallway. The planks that made up the floor rattled as she walked, and the plaster on the walls was broken and crumbling.

ʃi ɹitʃt ə dɔɹweɪ ən pikt ɪn. ðə smɔl tʃeɪmbɝ kənteɪn fɔɹ smɔl bɹæs bɛdz; ðə mætʃɹəsəz hæd stʃɹɔ pikɪŋ fɹəm ðə simz.

She reached a doorway and peeked in. The small chamber contained four small brass beds; the mattresses had straw peeking from the seams.

itʃ bɛd bɔɹ ə jʌŋ tʃaɪl klʌtʃɪŋ ə ɹæɾi blæŋkət. tu ʌv əm wɝ kɑfɪŋ, ən ɔl fɔɹ lʊk peɪl ən sɪkli.

Each bed bore a young child clutching a ratty blanket. Two of them were coughing, and all four looked pale and sickly.

nɪneɪiv ɡæspt, hɝiɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum. ʃi nɛl bɪsaɪd ðə fɝs tʃaɪld, ə bɔɪ ʌv pɝhæps fɔɹ jɪɹz. ʃi tʃɛkt ɪz aɪz, ðən toʊld ɪm tə kɑf əz ʃi lɪsən əɾ ɪz tʃɛst. hi hæd ðə kɹipɪŋ sɪknəs.

Nynaeve gasped, hurrying into the room. She knelt beside the first child, a boy of perhaps four years. She checked his eyes, then told him to cough as she listened at his chest. He had the creeping sickness.

"hu ɪz kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ju?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd.

"Who is caring for you?" Nynaeve demanded.

"mɪstʃɹəs mɑlə ɹʌnz ði ɔɹfənədʒ," ðə tʃaɪl sɛɾ ɪn ə wik vɔɪs. "wi hævən sin əɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm."

"Mistress Mala runs the orphanage," the child said in a weak voice. "We haven't seen her in a long time."

"pliz," ə jʌŋ ɡɝl sɛd fɹəm ðə nɛks bɛd. ʃi hæd blʌdʃɑɾ aɪz, hɝ skɪn soʊ peɪl ɪt wɑz pɹæktəkli waɪt. "sʌm wɔɾɝ? kəɾ aɪ hæv səm wɔɾɝ?" ʃi tʃɹɛmbəld.

"Please," a young girl said from the next bed. She had bloodshot eyes, her skin so pale it was practically white. "Some water? Could I have some water?" She trembled.

ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ kɹaɪɪŋ. pɪɾəfəl, wik saʊnz. laɪt! ðəɹ wɑzn ə sɪŋɡəl wɪndoʊ ɪn ðə ɹum, ən nɪneɪiv sɔ ɹoʊtʃɪz skʌɾəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə bɛdz. hu wəd liv tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn sətʃ kəndɪʃənz?

The other two were crying. Pitiful, weak sounds. Light! There wasn't a single window in the room, and Nynaeve saw roaches scuttling under the beds. Who would leave children in such conditions?

"hʌʃ," ʃi sɛd. "aɪm hɪɹ naʊ. əl kɛɹ fəɹ ju."

"Hush," she said. "I'm here now. I'll care for you."

ʃid nid tə tʃænəl tə hil ðɛm. ðən . . .

She'd need to channel to Heal them. Then . . .

noʊ, ʃi θɔt. / kæn də ðæt. aɪ kæn tʃænəl əntɪl aɪ ɹitʃ ðə stɑɹ.

No, she thought. / can't do that. I can't channel until I reach the star.

ʃi wəd bɹu dʒɹæfs, ðɛn. wɛɹ wɑz əɹ ɝb paʊtʃ? ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə sɔɹs ʌv wɔɾɝ.

She would brew draughts, then. Where was her herb pouch? She looked around the room, searching for a source of water.

ʃi fɹoʊz; ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹum əkɹɔs ðə hɔlweɪ. hæd ðət bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ? ə ɹʌɡ ɑn ɪts flɔɹ bɔɹ ðə sɪmbəl ə ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ. ʃi ɹoʊz. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɪmpɝd.

She froze; there was another room across the hallway. Had that been there before? A rug on its floor bore the symbol of the six-pointed star. She rose. The children whimpered.

"aɪl ɹɪtɝn," nɪneɪiv sɛd, stɛpɪŋ təwɔɹd ðət ɹum. itʃ stɛp twɪstəɾ əɹ hɑɹt. ʃi wɑz əbændənɪŋ ðɛm. bʌt noʊ, ʃi wɑz oʊnli wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə nɛkst ɹum. wɑznt ʃi?

"I'll return," Nynaeve said, stepping toward that room. Each step twisted her heart. She was abandoning them. But no, she was only walking into the next room. Wasn't she?

ʃi ɹitʃt ðə ɹʌɡ ən bɪɡæn tə wiv. dʒʌs ðɪs wʌn kwɪk wivɪŋ, ðən ʃi kəd hɛlp. ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf kɹaɪɪŋ əz ʃi wɝkt.

She reached the rug and began to weave. Just this one quick weaving, then she could help. She found herself crying as she worked.

aɪv bɪn hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ, ʃi θɔt. əɹ ə pleɪs laɪk ɪt. ə sɪtʃueɪʃən sətʃ əz ðɪs.

I've been here before, she thought. Or a place like it. A situation such as this.

ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf mɔɹ ən mɔɹ æŋɡɹi. haʊ kəd ʃi tʃænəl wɪð ðoʊz tʃɪlʒɹən kɔlɪŋ fəɹ hɝ? ðeɪ wɝ daɪɪŋ.

She found herself more and more angry. How could she channel with those children calling for her? They were dying.

ʃi kəmpliɾəd ðə wiv, ðən wɑtʃt ɪt bloʊ aʊt dʒɛts ʌv ɛɹ, ɹʌfəlɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛs. ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ əɹ bɹeɪɾ ən hɛld ɪɾ əz ə dɔɹ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. ə smɔl ɡlæs wɪndoʊ wɑz sɛɾ ɪndə ðə tɑp, ən ɪt bɔɹ ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ.

She completed the weave, then watched it blow out jets of air, ruffling her dress. She reached for her braid and held it as a door appeared on the side of the room. A small glass window was set into the top, and it bore the six-pointed star.

ʃi hæd tə kəntɪnju. ʃi hɝd ðə wipɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən. tɪɹz ɪn əɹ aɪz, hɑɹt bɹeɪkɪŋ, ʃi wɔk tə ðə dɔɹ.

She had to continue. She heard the weeping children. Tears in her eyes, heart breaking, she walked to the door.

ɪt ɡɹu wɝs. ʃi lɛf pipəl tə bi dʒɹaʊnd, bɪhɛɾɪd ən bɛɹiɾ əlaɪv-wʌn ə ðə wɝst wɑz wən ʃi hæd tə fɔɹm ə wiv waɪl vɪlɪdʒɝz wɝ kənsum baɪ ɪnɔɹməs spaɪɾɝz wɪð bɹaɪt ɹɛd fɝ ən kɹɪstəlaɪn aɪz. ʃi heɪɾəd spaɪɾɝz.

It grew worse. She left people to be drowned, beheaded and buried alive-One of the worst was when she had to form a weave while villagers were consumed by enormous spiders with bright red fur and crystalline eyes. She hated spiders.

səmtaɪmz ʃi wəɾ əpɪɹ neɪkəd. ðət stɑp bɑðɝɪŋ hɝ. ðoʊ ʃi kʊdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ spəsɪfɪk bʌt ðə nʌmbɝ ə ðə wiv ʃi wɑz ɑn, ʃi ʌndɝstʊd - sʌmhaʊ - ðət nuɾɪti wɑz nʌθɪŋ kəmpɛɹɛ tə ðə tɛɹɝz ʃid sin.

Sometimes she would appear naked. That stopped bothering her. Though she couldn't remember anything specific but the number of the weave she was on, she understood - somehow - that nudity was nothing comparedd to the terrors she'd seen.

ʃi stʌmbəl θɹu ə stoʊn ɑɹtʃweɪ, mɛmɹiz ʌv ə haʊs ɑn faɪɝ feɪɾɪŋ fɹəm əɹ maɪnd. ðɪs wɑz ði eɪɾi-fɝst wiv. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðæt. ðəɾ ən əɹ fjʊɹi.

She stumbled through a stone archway, memories of a house on fire fading from her mind. This was the eighty-first weave. She remembered that. That and her fury.

ʃi wɔɹ ə sɪŋʒd dʒɹɛs ə sæklɔθ. haʊ hæd ʃi bɝn ɪt? ʃi stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ɑɹmz θɹɑbɪŋ, bæk filɪŋ wɪpt, lɛɡz ən toʊz bɛɹɪŋ kʌts ən skɹætʃəz. ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɪksɛpt, ɪt wɑzn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. nɑɾ əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt. səm ə ðə bɪldɪŋz smoʊldɝd, stɪl bɝnɪŋ.

She wore a singed dress of sackcloth. How had she burned it? She stood up straight, holding her head, arms throbbing, back feeling whipped, legs and toes bearing cuts and scratches. She was in the Two Rivers. Except, it wasn't the Two Rivers. Not as she remembered it. Some of the buildings smoldered, still burning.

"ðeɪɹ kʌmɪŋ əɡɛn!" ə vɔɪs jɛld. mæstɝ ælvɪɹ. waɪ wɑz i hoʊldɪŋ ə sɔɹd? pipəl ʃi nu, pipəl dɪɹ tə hɝ - pɛɹɪn, mæstɝ ælvɪɹ, mɪstʃɹəs ɑldənəl, ɪɹi bɑɾɪɡɝ - stʊd bɪsaɪɾ ə loʊ wɔl, ɔl hoʊldɪŋ wɛpənz. səm weɪv tə hɝ.

"They're coming again!" a voice yelled. Master al'Vere. Why was he holding a sword? People she knew, people dear to her - Perrin, Master al'Vere, Mistress al'Donel, Aerie Botteger - stood beside a low wall, all holding weapons. Some waved to her.

"nɪneɪiv!" pɛɹɪn kɔld. "ʃæɾoʊzpɔn! wi nid jəɹ hɛlp!"

"Nynaeve!" Perrin called. "Shadowspawn! We need your help!"

ɪnɔɹməs ʃædoʊz muvd ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl. ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ə tɛɹəbəl saɪz - nɑt tʃɹɑləks, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹ wɝs. ʃi kəd hɪɹ ɹɔɹz.

Enormous shadows moved on the other side of the wall. Shadowspawn of terrible size - not Trollocs, but something far worse. She could hear roars.

ʃi hæd tə hɛlp! ʃi muv təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn, bʌt fɹoʊz əz ʃi sɔ -  əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən - ə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ peɪntəɾ ɑn ə hɪlsaɪd.

She had to help! She moved toward Perrin, but froze as she saw -  across the Green in the other direction - a six-pointed star painted on a hillside.

"nɪneɪiv!" pɛɹɪn saʊndəd dɛspɹɪt. hi bɪɡæn stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ðə wɔl, tɛntəkəlz ə mɪdnaɪt blæk. pɛɹɪn tʃɑpt əɾ əm wɪð ən æks əz wʌn snætʃt ʌp ɪɹi ən pʊld ɪm - skɹimɪŋ -  ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

"Nynaeve!" Perrin sounded desperate. He began striking at something that reached over the wall, tentacles of midnight black. Perrin chopped at them with an axe as one snatched up Aerie and pulled him - screaming -  into the darkness.

nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn tə wɔk təwɔɹd ðə stɑɹ. kɑm. mɛʒɝd.

Nynaeve began to walk toward the star. Calm. Measured.

ðət wɑz stupəd. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd tə bi kɑm. ʃi nu ðæt. bʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlsoʊ niɾəd tə bi eɪbəl tə ækt, tə də wʌt wɑz niɾəd tə hɛlp ðoʊz u niɾəd ɪt. ɪt dɪdn mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪt kɑst əɹ pɝsənəli. ðiz pipəl niɾəd hɝ.

That was stupid. An Aes Sedai had to be calm. She knew that. But an Aes Sedai also needed to be able to act, to do what was needed to help those who needed it. It didn't matter what it cost her personally. These people needed her.

soʊ ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə ɹʌn.

So she started to run.

ivən ðət dɪdn fil laɪk ɪnʌf. ʃi ɹæn tə ɡɛt tə ðə stɑɹ, bʌt stɪl ʃi lɛf pipəl ʃi lʌv tə faɪɾ əloʊn. ʃi nu ʃi kʊdn tʃænəl əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ. ðət meɪɾ æbsəlutli noʊ sɛns. ʃæɾoʊzpɔn wɝ ətækɪŋ. ʃi hæd tə tʃænəl!

Even that didn't feel like enough. She ran to get to the star, but still she left people she loved to fight alone. She knew she couldn't channel until she reached the six-pointed star. That made absolutely no sense. Shadowspawn were attacking. She had to channel!

ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, ən sʌmθɪŋ sim tə tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɝ. sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ə ʃild. ʃi pʊʃt ɪɾ əsaɪd wɪð dɪfəkəlti ən paʊɝ flʌɾəd hɝ. ʃi bɪɡæn flɪŋɪŋ faɪɝ ət ðə mɑnstɝ, bɝnɪŋ ɔf ə tɛntəkəl əz ɪt ɡɹæb fəɹ pɛɹɪn.

She embraced the Source, and something seemed to try to stop her. Something like a shield. She pushed it aside with difficulty and Power flooded her. She began flinging fire at the monster, burning off a tentacle as it grabbed for Perrin.

nɪneɪiv kəntɪnjud θɹoʊɪŋ faɪɝ əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ. ðɛɹ, ʃi woʊv ði eɪɾi-fɝst wiv, wɪtʃ kɹieɪɾəd θɹi ɹɪŋz ə faɪɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

Nynaeve continued throwing fire until she reached the six-pointed star. There, she wove the eighty-first weave, which created three rings of Fire in the air.

ʃi wɝk fjʊɹiəsli, ətækɪŋ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ ðə pɔɪn ə kɹieɪɾɪŋ ðɪs wiv, bʌt ʃi nu ʃi hæd tə fɪnɪʃ ɪt. soʊ ʃi ɪn-kɹis ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðə wiv, meɪkɪŋ ðə bɝnɪŋ ɹɪŋz ɪkstʃɹimli lɑɹdʒ. ðən ʃi bɪɡæn hɝlɪŋ əm ət ðə kɹitʃɝz. mæsɪv heɪloʊz ʌv) fleɪm kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə dɑɹk θɪŋz, kɪlɪŋ ðɛm.

She worked furiously, attacking at the same time. She didn't know the point of creating this weave, but she knew she had to finish it. So she in-creased the strength of the weave, making the burning rings extremely large. Then she began hurling them at the creatures. Massive halos of) flame crashed into the dark things, killing them.

ðəɹ wɑz ə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ ɑn ðə ɹuf ə mæstɝ æl 'viɹz ɪn. hæɾ ɪt bɪn bɝn ðɛɹ?

There was a six-pointed star on the roof of Master al 'Veres inn. Had it been burned there?

nɪneɪiv ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt, vɛntɪŋ əɹ æŋɡɝ ət ðə θɪŋz wɪð tɛntəkəlz.

Nynaeve ignored it, venting her anger at the things with tentacles.

noʊ. ðɪs ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ ɑn.

No. This is important. More important than the Two Rivers. I must go on.

filɪŋ laɪk ən ʌɾɝ kaʊɝd - bʌt noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə də - ʃi ɹæn tə ði ɪn, pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ.

Feeling like an utter coward - but knowing it was the right thing to do - she ran to the inn, passing through the doorway.

nɪneɪiv leɪ wipɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪɾ ə bɹoʊkən ɑɹtʃweɪ. ʃi wɑz ɑn ðə læst ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz.

Nynaeve lay weeping on the ground beside a broken archway. She was on the last of the hundred weaves.

ʃi kəd bɛɹli muv. hɝ feɪs wɑz stʃɹikt wɪð tɪɹz. ʃi hæd hɑloʊ mɛmɹiz ə fliɪŋ bæɾəlz, ʌv livɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən tə daɪ. ʌv nɛvɝ biɪŋ eɪbəl tə də ɪnʌf.

She could barely move. Her face was streaked with tears. She had hollow memories of fleeing battles, of leaving children to die. Of never being able to do enough.

hɝ ʃoʊldɝ blɛd. ə wʊlfs baɪt. hɝ lɛɡz wɝ fleɪd, əz ɪf ʃid wɔk θɹu ə lɔŋ pætʃ ə θɔɹnz. ɔl əkɹɔs əɹ bɑɾi wɝ bɝnz ən blɪstɝz. ʃi wɑz neɪkəd.

Her shoulder bled. A wolf's bite. Her legs were flayed, as if she'd walked through a long patch of thorns. All across her body were burns and blisters. She was naked.

ʃi ɹoʊz tə hɝ niz, wɪtʃ wɝ skɹeɪpt ən bliɾɪŋ. hɝ bɹeɪɾ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə smoʊldɝɪŋ stʌmp əbaʊɾ ə hændspæn bɪloʊ hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. ʃi ɹɛtʃt tə ðə saɪd, ʃɪvɝɪŋ.

She rose to her knees, which were scraped and bleeding. Her braid ended in a smoldering stump about a handspan below her shoulders. She retched to the side, shivering.

soʊ sɪk, soʊ wik. haʊ kəd ʃi kəntɪnju?

So sick, so weak. How could she continue?

noʊ. ðəl nɑt bit mi.

No. They will not beat me.

ʃi sloʊli ɹeɪz hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit. ʃi wɑz ɪn ə smɔl ɹum, hɑɹʃ sʌnlaɪt likɪŋ θɹu kɹæks bɪtwin ðə wɔlbɔɹdz. ə bʌndəl ʌv waɪt klɔθ leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp, ənfoʊldɪŋ ɪt. ɪt wɑz ə waɪt dʒɹɛs wɪð ðə kʌlɝz ə ði ədʒəz bændɪɾ ət ðə bɑɾəm. ðə kloʊðɪŋ ʌv ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

She slowly raised herself to her feet. She was in a small room, harsh sunlight leaking through cracks between the wallboards. A bundle of white cloth lay on the ground. She picked it up, unfolding it. It was a white dress with the colors of the Ajahs banded at the bottom. The clothing of an Accepted in the White Tower.

ʃi dʒɹɑpt ɪt. "aɪ æm ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹoʊb ən pʊʃɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

She dropped it. "I am Aes Sedai," she said, stepping over the robe and pushing open the door.

bɛɾɝ tə ɡoʊ neɪkəd ðən tə ɡɪv ɪn tə ðət laɪ.

Better to go naked than to give in to that lie.

aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, ʃi faʊn ənʌðɝ dʒɹɛs, ðɪs taɪm jɛloʊ. ðət wɑz mɔɹ pɹɑpɝ. ʃi əlaʊd hɝsɛlf ðə taɪm tə pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn, ðoʊ ʃi kʊdn stɑp tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, ən əɹ fɪŋɡɝz wɝ soʊ taɪɝd ʃi kəd bɛɹli meɪk əm wɝk. hɝ blʌd steɪn ðə klɔθ.

Outside the door, she found another dress, this time yellow. That was more proper. She allowed herself the time to put it on, though she couldn't stop trembling, and her fingers were so tired she could barely make them work. Her blood stained the cloth.

dʒɹɛs ɑn, ʃi ɪnspɛktɪɾ əɹ sɝaʊndɪŋz. ʃi wɑz ɑn ə hɪlsaɪɾ ɪn ðə blaɪt, ðə ɡɹaʊn kʌvɝɾ ɪn widz ðət bɔɹ ðə dɪstɪŋktɪv dɑɹk mɑɹks. waɪ wɑz ðəɹ ə ʃæk ɪn ðə blaɪt, ən waɪ hæd ʃi bɪn ɪnsaɪɾ ʌv ɪt?

Dress on, she inspected her surroundings. She was on a hillside in the Blight, the ground covered in weeds that bore the distinctive dark marks. Why was there a shack in the Blight, and why had she been inside of it?

ʃi fɛl soʊ taɪɝd. ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ bæk ɪndə ðə ʃæk ən slip.

She felt so tired. She wanted to go back into the shack and sleep.

noʊ. ʃi wəd kəntɪnju. ʃi tʃɹʌdʒd ʌp ðə hɪl. əɾ ɪts tɑp, ʃi lʊk daʊn ɑn ə læn kʌvɝɾ ɪn bɹoʊkən ɹʌbəl ən pɑkəts ə dɑɹknəs. leɪks, ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi kɔl ðæt. ðə lɪkwəd lʊk θɪk ən ɔɪli. dɑɹk ʃeɪps muvd wɪðɪn ðɛm. mɔlkiɝ, ʃi θɔt, stʌn ðət ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə pleɪs.

No. She would continue. She trudged up the hill. At its top, she looked down on a land covered in broken rubble and pockets of darkness. Lakes, if they could be called that. The liquid looked thick and oily. Dark shapes moved within them. Malkier, she thought, stunned that she recognized the place.

ðə sɛvən taʊɝz, oʊnli ɹʌbəl naʊ. ðə θaʊzən leɪks kɝʌptɪd. ðə pleɪs ə lænz hɛɹəɾədʒ.

The Seven Towers, only rubble now. The Thousand Lakes corrupted. The place of Lan's heritage.

ʃi stɛp fɔɹwɝd, bʌɾ əɹ toʊ hɪt sʌmθɪŋ. ə stoʊn bɪniθ əɹ fit hæd bɪn kɑɹvd wɪð ə smɔl sɪmbəl. ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ.

She stepped forward, but her toe hit something. A stone beneath her feet had been carved with a small symbol. The six-pointed star.

ʃi saɪɾ ɪn ɹɪlif. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs θɹu. ʃi bɪɡæn ðə faɪnəl wiv.

She sighed in relief. It was almost through. She began the final weave.

bɪloʊ, ə mæn stʌmbəld aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ə maʊn ə ɹʌbəl, swɪŋɪŋ ɛkspɝtli wɪð ɪz sɔɹd.

Below, a man stumbled out from behind a mound of rubble, swinging expertly with his sword.

ʃi nu hɪm ivən əɾ ə dɪstəns. ðət stʃɹɔŋ fɪɡjɝ, skwɛɹ feɪs, kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk ən deɪnʒɝəs weɪ ʌv wɔkɪŋ.

She knew him even at a distance. That strong figure, square face, color-shifting cloak and dangerous way of walking.

"læn!" ʃi skɹimd.

"Lan!" she screamed.

hi wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ bists ðət lʊk laɪk wʊlvz, bʌt tu lɑɹdʒ. ðeɪ hæd dɑɹk fɝ, ən ðɛɹ tiθ flæʃt əz ðeɪ lʌnʒd təwɔɹd læn. dɑɹkhaʊnz, ən ɪntaɪɝ pæk.

He was surrounded by beasts that looked like wolves, but too large. They had dark fur, and their teeth flashed as they lunged toward Lan. Darkhounds, an entire pack.

nɪneɪiv fɪnɪʃt ðə hʌnʒɹədθ wiv wɪð ə stɑɹt; ʃi hædn ɹilaɪzd ʃid kəntɪnjuɾ ɪt. ə ʃaʊɝ ə kʌlɝfəl spɛks bɝst ɪndə ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi wɑtʃt əm fɔl, filɪŋ juzd. ʃi hɝɾ ə saʊn oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt wən ʃi ɡlænst, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðɛɹ. dʒʌs ðə ʃæk.

Nynaeve finished the hundredth weave with a start; she hadn't realized she'd continued it. A shower of colorful specks burst into the air around her. She watched them fall, feeling used. She heard a sound over her shoulder, but when she glanced, there was nothing there. Just the shack.

ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ hʌŋ oʊvɝ ə dɔɹ ðɛɹ, ðə sɪmbəl meɪɾ ə bɪts ə dʒɛmstoʊnz. ðət dɔɹ hædn bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ. ʃi tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd ðə ʃæk, ðən lʊk bæk.

The six-pointed star hung over a door there, the symbol made of bits of gemstones. That door hadn't been there before. She took a step toward the shack, then looked back.

læn swʌŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm wɪð ɪz sɔɹd, fɔɹsɪŋ ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz əweɪ. wʌn bɪɾ ə səlaɪvə fɹəm ðoʊz bists wəd kɪl hɪm.

Lan swung about him with his sword, forcing the Darkhounds away. One bit of saliva from those beasts would kill him.

"læn," ʃi skɹimd. "ɹʌn!"

"Lan," she screamed. "Run!"

hi dɪdn hɪɹ hɝ. ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ. ʃi niɾəd tə wɔk tə ɪt!

He didn't hear her. The six-pointed star. She needed to walk to it!

ʃi blɪŋkt, ðən lʊk daʊn əɾ əɹ hænz. ɪn ðə dɝɛk sɛntɝ ʌv itʃ pɑm wɑz ə taɪni skɑɹ.

She blinked, then looked down at her hands. In the direct center of each palm was a tiny scar.

ɔlmoʊst ənnɑɾəsəbəl. siɪŋ əm spɑɹkt ə mɛmɹi ɪn hɝ.

Almost unnoticeable. Seeing them sparked a memory in her.

nɪneɪiv . . . aɪ lʌv jə . . .

Nynaeve . . . I love you . . .

ðɪs wɑz ə tɛst. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət naʊ. ɪt wɑz ə tɛs tə fɔɹs əɹ tə tʃuz bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ʃid meɪd ðət tʃɔɪs wʌns, bʌt ʃid noʊn ɪt wɑzn ɹil.

This was a test. She could remember that now. It was a test to force her to choose between him and the White Tower. She'd made that choice once, but she'd known it wasn't real.

ðɪs wɑzn ɹil iðɝ, wɑz ɪt? ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ hɛd, maɪn klaʊɾi. ðəɾ ɪz maɪ hʌzbən daʊn ðɛɹ, ʃi θɔt. noʊ. əl nɑt pleɪ ðɪs ɡeɪm!

This wasn't real either, was it? She raised a hand to her head, mind cloudy. That is my husband down there, she thought. No. I will not play this game!

ʃi skɹimd, wivɪŋ faɪɝ ən θɹoʊɪŋ ɪt təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə dɑɹk-haʊnz. ðə kɹitʃɝ bɝst ɪndə fleɪmz, bʌt ðə faɪɝ dɪdn sim tə hɝɾ ɪt. nɪneɪiv stɛp fɔɹwɝd, θɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ faɪɝ. jusləs!

She screamed, weaving Fire and throwing it toward one of the Dark-hounds. The creature burst into flames, but the fire didn't seem to hurt it. Nynaeve stepped forward, throwing more fire. Useless!

ðə haʊnz dʒʌs kɛpt ətækɪŋ.

The hounds just kept attacking.

ʃi ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ɪn tə hɝ ɪɡzɔstʃən. ʃi bænɪʃt ɪt, ɡɹoʊɪŋ kɑm kəntʃɹoʊld. aɪs. ðeɪ wɑntəd tə pʊʃ hɝ, si wʌt ʃi kəd du? wɛl, lɛɾ ɪt bi. ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪn ən ɪmɛns əmaʊn ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

She refused to give in to her exhaustion. She banished it, growing calm controlled. Ice. They wanted to push her, see what she could do? Well, let it be. She reached out, drawing in an immense amount of the One Power.

ðən ʃi woʊv bɑlfaɪɝ.

Then she wove balefire.

ðə laɪn ə pjʊɹ laɪt spɹæŋ fɹəm əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, wɔɹpɪŋ ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɪt. ʃi hɪt wʌn ə ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz ən sim tə pʌŋktʃɝ ɪt, ðə laɪt kəntɪnjuɪŋ ɑn ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ði ɪntaɪɝ lændskeɪp ɹʌmbəld, ən nɪneɪiv stʌmbəld. læn fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz lɛpt ət hɪm.

The line of pure light sprang from her fingers, warping the air around it. She hit one of the Darkhounds and seemed to puncture it, the light continuing on into the ground. The entire landscape rumbled, and Nynaeve stumbled. Lan fell to the ground. The Darkhounds leaped at him.

noʊ! nɪneɪiv θɔt, ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf, wivɪŋ bɑlfaɪɝ əɡɛn. ʃi blæstəɾ ənʌðɝ haʊnd, ðən ənʌðɝ. mɔɹ ə ðə mɑnstɝz lɛp fɹəm bɪhaɪn ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃənz. wɛɹ wɝ ðeɪ ɔl kʌmɪŋ fɹʌm? nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd, blæstɪŋ wɪð ðə fɔɹbɪɾən wiv.

NO! Nynaeve thought, righting herself, weaving balefire again. She blasted another hound, then another. More of the monsters leaped from behind rock formations. Where were they all coming from? Nynaeve strode forward, blasting with the forbidden weave.

itʃ stʃɹaɪk meɪd ðə ɡɹaʊn tʃɹɛmbəl, əz ɪf ɪn peɪn. ðə bɑlfaɪɝ ʃʊdn pʌŋktʃɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn laɪk ðæt. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ.

Each strike made the ground tremble, as if in pain. The balefire shouldn't puncture the ground like that. Something was wrong.

ʃi ɹitʃt lænz saɪd. hi hæd bɹoʊkən ɪz lɛɡ. "nɪneɪiv!" hi sɛd. "ju mʌst ɡoʊ!"

She reached Lan's side. He had broken his leg. "Nynaeve!" he said. "You must go!"

ʃi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪz wɝdz, nilɪŋ daʊn ən wivɪŋ bɑlfaɪɝ əz ənʌðɝ haʊn ɹaʊndəd ðə ɹʌbəl.

She ignored his words, kneeling down and weaving balefire as another hound rounded the rubble.

ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ wɑz ɪnkɹisɪŋ, ən ʃi wɑz soʊ taɪɝd. itʃ taɪm ʃi tʃænəld, ʃi fɛlt ɪt wəd ʃʊɹli bi hɝ læst.

Their number was increasing, and she was so tired. Each time she channeled, she felt it would surely be her last.

bʌɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi. nɑt wɪð læn ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ʃi woʊv ə kɑmplɛks hilɪŋ, pʊɾɪŋ ɛvɹi bɪɾ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ʃi hæd lɛft ɪndə ɪt, mɛndɪŋ ɪz lɛɡ. hi skɹæmbəld ʌp ən ɡɹæbd ɪz sɔɹd, tɝnɪŋ tə fɛn ɔf ə dɑɹkhaʊnd.

But it could not be. Not with Lan in danger. She wove a complex Healing, putting every bit of strength she had left into it, mending his leg. He scrambled up and grabbed his sword, turning to fend off a Darkhound.

ðeɪ fɔt təɡɛðɝ, hɝ wɪð bɑlfaɪɝ, hɪm wɪð stil. bʌɾ ɪz swɪŋz wɝ ləθɑɹdʒɪk, ən ɪt tʊk əɹ ə fju hɑɹtbits lɔŋɡɝ itʃ taɪm ʃi meɪd ðə bɑlfaɪɝ. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ ən ɹʌmbəlɪŋ, ɹuənz kɹæʃɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

They fought together, her with balefire, him with steel. But his swings were lethargic, and it took her a few heartbeats longer each time she made the balefire. The ground was shaking and rumbling, ruins crashing to the ground.

"læn!" ʃi sɛd. "bi ɹɛɾi tə ɹʌn!"

"Lan!" she said. "Be ready to run!"

"wʌt?"

"What?"

wɪð əɹ læst aʊns ə stʃɹɛŋkθ, ʃi woʊv bɑlfaɪɝ ən eɪmd ɪt dɝɛkli daʊnwɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. ðə ɡɹaʊn ənʒəleɪtɪd ɪn æɡəni, ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ. ði ɝθ splɪt nɪɹbaɪ, dɑɹkhaʊnz tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn. nɪneɪiv kəlæpst, ðə wʌn paʊɝ slɪpɪŋ fɹəm hɝ. ʃi wɑz tu taɪɝd tə tʃænəl.

With her last ounce of strength, she wove balefire and aimed it directly downward in front of them. The ground undulated in agony, almost like a living thing. The earth split nearby, Darkhounds tumbling in. Nynaeve collapsed, the One Power slipping from her. She was too tired to channel.

læn ɡɹæbd əɹ ɑɹm. "wi mʌst ɡoʊ!"

Lan grabbed her arm. "We must go!"

ʃi hɔl hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit, teɪkɪŋ ɪz hænd. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ ɹæn ʌp ðə ɹʌmbəlɪŋ hɪlsaɪd.

She hauled herself to her feet, taking his hand. Together, they ran up the rumbling hillside.

dɑɹkhaʊnz haʊl bɪhaɪnd, səm ə ðə pæk lipɪŋ ðə ɹɪft.

Darkhounds howled behind, some of the pack leaping the rift.

nɪneɪiv ɹæn fəɹ ɔl ʃi wɑz wɝθ, klɪŋɪŋ tə lænz hænd. ðeɪ kɹɛstəd ðə hɪl. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ soʊ tɛɹəbli, ʃi kʊdn bɪliv ðə ʃæk stɪl stændɪŋ. ʃi stʌmbəl daʊn ðə hɪl təwɔɹɾ ɪt, læn wɪð hɝ.

Nynaeve ran for all she was worth, clinging to Lan's hand. They crested the hill. The ground was shaking so terribly, she couldn't believe the shack still standing. She stumbled down the hill toward it, Lan with her.

hi tʃɹɪpt, kɹaɪɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn peɪn. hɪz hæn slɪp fɹəm əɹ fɪŋɡɝz.

He tripped, crying out in pain. His hand slipped from her fingers.

ʃi spʌn. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ə flʌɾ ə dɑɹkhaʊnz kɹɛstəd ðə hɪltɑp, snɑɹlɪŋ, tiθ flæʃɪŋ ən spɪɾəl flaɪɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ maʊðz. læn weɪv fəɹ əɹ tə ɡoʊ, hɪz aɪz waɪd.

She spun. Behind them, a flood of Darkhounds crested the hilltop, snarling, teeth flashing and spittle flying from their mouths. Lan waved for her to go, his eyes wide.

"noʊ." ʃi ɡɹæbd ɪm baɪ ði ɑɹm ænd, hivɪŋ, hɔld ɪm daʊn ðə sloʊp. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ tʌmbəl θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ, ən . . .

"No." She grabbed him by the arm and, heaving, hauled him down the slope. Together, they tumbled through the doorway, and . . .

ən ɡæspɪŋ, nɪneɪiv fɛl fɹəm ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ʃi kəlæpst əloʊn ɑn ðə koʊl flɔɹ, neɪkəd, ʃeɪkɪŋ. ɪn ə flʌd, ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl. itʃ ən ɛvɹi hɔɹəbəl moʊmən ə ðə tɛst. itʃ bɪtʃɹeɪəl, itʃ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ wiv. ði ɪmpəɾəns, ðə skɹimz ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ðə dɛθs ə pipəl ʃi nu ən lʌvd. ʃi wɛpt əɡɛns ðə flɔɹ, kɝlɪŋ ʌp.

and gasping, Nynaeve fell from the ter'angreal. She collapsed alone on the cold floor, naked, shaking. In a flood, she remembered it all. Each and every horrible moment of the test. Each betrayal, each frustrating weave. The impotence, the screams of the children, the deaths of people she knew and loved. She wept against the floor, curling up.

hɝ ɪntaɪɝ bɑɾi wɑz əfaɪɹ wɪð peɪn. hɝ ʃoʊldɝ, lɛɡz, ɑɹmz ən bæk stɪl blɛd. ʃi wɑz bɝn tə blɪstɝz ɪn swɑθs əkɹɔs əɹ bɑɾi, ən ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɝ bɹeɪd wɑz ɡɔn. hɝ ənɹævəl hɛɹ fɛl əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə bænɪʃ ðə mɛmɹiz ʌv wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn.

Her entire body was afire with pain. Her shoulder, legs, arms and back still bled. She was burned to blisters in swaths across her body, and the greater part of her braid was gone. Her unraveled hair fell across her face as she tried to banish the memories of what she had done.

ʃi hɝd ɡɹoʊnz fɹəm nɪɹbaɪ, ən θɹu blɪɹi aɪz ʃi sɔ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə sɝkəl bɹeɪk ɔf ðɛɹ wivz ən slʌmp. ʃi heɪɾəd ðɛm. ʃi heɪɾəd itʃ ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm.

She heard groans from nearby, and through bleary eyes she saw the Aes Sedai in the circle break off their weaves and slump. She hated them. She hated each and every one of them.

"laɪt!" sɹɪnz vɔɪs. "sʌmwʌn hil hɝ!"

"Light!" Saerin's voice. "Someone Heal her!"

ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ blɝi. vɔɪsəz ɡɹu mʌɾəld. laɪk saʊnz ʌndɝ wɔɾɝ. pisfəl saʊnz . . .

Everything was growing blurry. Voices grew muddled. Like sounds under water. Peaceful sounds . . .

sʌmθɪŋ koʊld wɑʃt oʊvɝ hɝ. ʃi ɡæspt, hɝ aɪz oʊpənɪŋ waɪɾ ət ði aɪsi ʃɑk ə ðə hilɪŋ. ɹɑsɪl nɛl bɪsaɪd hɝ. ðə wʊmən lʊkt wɝid.

Something cold washed over her. She gasped, her eyes opening wide at the icy shock of the Healing. Rosil knelt beside her. The woman looked worried.

ðə peɪn lɛf nɪneɪivz bɑɾi, bʌɾ əɹ ɪɡzɔstʃən ɪnkɹis tɛnfoʊld. ən ðə peɪn ɪnsaɪd ... ɪt ɹɪmeɪnd. oʊ, laɪt. ʃi kəd hɪɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən skɹimɪŋ.

The pain left Nynaeve's body, but her exhaustion increased tenfold. And the pain inside ... it remained. Oh, Light. She could hear the children screaming.

"wɛl," sɹɪn sɛd fɹəm nɪɹbaɪ, "simz ðət ʃɪl lɪv. naʊ, wəd sʌmwʌn pliz tɛl mi wʌɾ ɪn ðə neɪm ə kɹieɪʃən ɪtsɛlf ðət wɑz?" ʃi saʊndəd fjʊɹiəs. "aɪv bɪn ə pɑɹɾ ə mɛni ə ɹeɪzɪŋ, ivən wʌn wɛɹ ðə wʊmən dɪdn sɝvaɪv. bʌɾ aɪ hæv nɛvɝ, ɪn ɔl ə maɪ deɪz, sin ə wʊmən pʊt θɹu wʌt ðɪs wʌn dʒʌst sʌfɝd."

"Well," Saerin said from nearby, "seems that she'll live. Now, would someone please tell me what in the name of creation itself that was?" She sounded furious. "I've been a part of many a raising, even one where the woman didn't survive. But I have never, in all of my days, seen a woman put through what this one just suffered."

ʃi hæd tə bi tɛstəd pɹɑpɝli," ɹubɪn sɛd.

She had to be tested properly," Rubinde said.

pɹɑpɝli?" sɹɪn dɪmændəd, lɪvɪd.

Properly?" Saerin demanded, livid.

nɪneɪiv dɪdn əv ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə lʊk ət ðɛm. ʃi leɪ, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt.

Nynaeve didn't have the strength to look at them. She lay, breathing in and out.

"pɹɑpɝli?" sɹɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd. "ðæt wɑzn pɹɑpɝ. ðət wɑz daʊnɹaɪt, vɛnʒfəl, ɹubɪnd!

"Properly?" Saerin repeated. "That wasn't proper. That was downright, vengeful, Rubinde!

ɔlmoʊst ɛni wʌn ə ðoʊz tɛsts wɑz bɪɑnd wʌɾ aɪv sin dɪmændəɾ ʌv ʌðɝ wɪmən. jə ʃəd bi əʃeɪmd. ɔl ə ju. laɪt, lʊk wʌt juv dʌn tə ðə ɡɝl!"

Almost any one of those tests was beyond what I've seen demanded of other women. You should be ashamed. All of you. Light, look what you've done to the girl!"

"ɪɾ ɪz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt," bɑɹɑsin ðə ɹɛd sɛɾ ɪn ə koʊl vɔɪs. "ʃi feɪl ðə tɛst."

"It is unimportant," Barasine the Red said in a cold voice. "She failed the test."

"wʌt?" nɪneɪiv kɹoʊkt, faɪnəli lʊkɪŋ ʌp. ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil hæd fɔlən dɪm, ən ɹɑsɪl hæd fɛtʃt ə blæŋkəɾ ən nɪneɪivz kloʊðɪŋ. ɛɡwin stʊd tə ðə saɪd, ɑɹmz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɝ. hɝ feɪs wɑz sɝin əz ʃi lɪsən tə ði ʌðɝz. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ə voʊt, bʌt ði ʌðɝz wʊd, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wɛðɝ nɪneɪiv hæd pæs ðə tɛst əɹ nɑt.

"What?" Nynaeve croaked, finally looking up. The ter'angreal had fallen dim, and Rosil had fetched a blanket and Nynaeve's clothing. Egwene stood to the side, arms clasped before her. Her face was serene as she listened to the others. She would not have a vote, but the others would, regarding whether Nynaeve had passed the test or not.

"ju feɪld, tʃaɪld" bɑɹɑsin sɛd, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ nɪneɪiv wɪð ən ɪmoʊʃənləs stɛɹ. "ju dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ pɹɑpɝ dɪkɔɹəm."

"You failed, child" Barasine said, regarding Nynaeve with an emotionless stare. "You did not show proper decorum."

ləleɪn ə ðə blu nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ ənɔɪd tə bi əɡɹiɪŋ wɪð ə ɹɛd. "ðɪs wɑz tə tɛs jəɹ əbɪləɾi tə bi kɑm əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ ðæt."

Lelaine of the Blue nodded, looking annoyed to be agreeing with a Red. "This was to test your ability to be calm as an Aes Sedai. You did not show that."

ði ʌðɝz lʊkt ənkʌmftəɹbəl. jə wɝn səpoʊz tə spik ə ðə spɪsɪfɪks ʌv ə tɛstɪŋ.

The others looked uncomfortable. You weren't supposed to speak of the specifics of a testing.

nɪneɪiv nu ðət mʌtʃ. ʃi ɔlsoʊ nu ðət moʊst ə ðə taɪm, feɪlɪŋ ən daɪɪŋ wɝ ðə seɪm θɪŋ.

Nynaeve knew that much. She also knew that most of the time, failing and dying were the same thing.

ðoʊ ʃi wɑzn tɛɹəbli sɝpɹaɪz tə hɪɹ kleɪmz ðət ʃid feɪld, naʊ ðət ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt.

Though she wasn't terribly surprised to hear claims that she'd failed, now that she thought about it.

ʃi hæd bɹoʊkən ðə ɹulz ə ðə tɛst. ʃid ɹʌn ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə seɪv pɛɹɪn ən ʌðɝz. ʃid tʃænəl bɪfɔɹ ʃi ʃəd hæv. ʃi hæd tʃɹʌbəl sʌmənɪŋ ɹəɡɹɛt. ɛvɹi ʌðɝ ɪmoʊʃən wɑz, fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, kənsum baɪ ðə hɑloʊ lɔs ʃi fɛlt.

She had broken the rules of the test. She'd run in order to save Perrin and others. She'd channeled before she should have. She had trouble summoning regret. Every other emotion was, for the moment, consumed by the hollow loss she felt.

"bɑɹɑsin dʌz əv ə pɔɪnt," sin sɛd, ɹɪlʌktənt. "baɪ ði ɛnd, jə wɝ oʊpənli fjʊɹiəs, ən jə ɹæn tə ɹitʃ mɛni ʌv ðə mɑɹkɝz. ən ðən ðəɹ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ ə ðə fɔɹbɪɾən wiv. moʊs tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ. aɪ də nɑt seɪ jə ʃəd feɪl, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾiz."

"Barasine does have a point," Seaine said, reluctant. "By the end, you were openly furious, and you ran to reach many of the markers. And then there is the matter of the forbidden weave. Most troubling. I do not say you should fail, but there are irregularities."

nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə klaɪm tə hɝ fit. ɹɑsɪl pleɪst ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə fɝbɪd hɝ, bʌt nɪneɪiv tʊk ði ɑɹm ən juzd ɪɾ əz səpɔɹt, pʊlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp ɑn ənstɛɾi lɛɡz. ʃi tʊk ðə blæŋkəɾ ən ɹæpt ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, hoʊldɪŋ ɪt kloʊzd ət ðə fɹʌnt.

Nynaeve tried to climb to her feet. Rosil placed a hand on her shoulder to forbid her, but Nynaeve took the arm and used it as support, pulling herself up on unsteady legs. She took the blanket and wrapped it around her shoulders, holding it closed at the front.

ʃi fɛl soʊ dʒɹeɪnd. "aɪ dɪd wʌɾ aɪ hæd tə. hu əmʌŋ jə wəd nɑt ɹʌn ɪf jə sɔ pipəl ɪn deɪnʒɝ? hu əmʌŋ jə wəd fɝbɪd hɝsɛlf tə tʃænəl ɪf ʃi sɔ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ətækɪŋ? aɪ æktəɾ əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊd.

She felt so drained. "I did what I had to. Who among you would not run if you saw people in danger? Who among you would forbid herself to channel if she saw Shadowspawn attacking? I acted as an Aes Sedai should.

"ðɪs tɛst," bɑɹɑsin sɛd, "ɪz mɛn tə ɛnʃʊɹ ðəɾ ə wʊmən ɪz keɪpəbəl ə dɛɾɪkeɪtɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ tæsk. tə si ðət ʃi kən ɪɡnɔɹ ðə dɪstʃɹækʃənz ə ðə moʊmən ən sik ə haɪɝ ɡʊd."

"This test," Barasine said, "is meant to ensure that a woman is capable of dedicating herself to a greater task. To see that she can ignore the distractions of the moment and seek a higher good."

nɪneɪiv snɪft. "aɪ kəmpliɾəd ðə wivz aɪ niɾəd tə. aɪ meɪnteɪn maɪ foʊkəs. jɛs, aɪ bɹoʊk maɪ kɑm - bʌɾ aɪ kɛpt ə kul ɪnʌf hɛd tə kɑm- plit maɪ tæsks. wʌn ʃəd nɑt dɪmæn kɑmnəs fəɹ ðə mɪɹ seɪk ə kɑmnəs, ən ə pɹoʊəbɪʃən ɑn ɹʌnɪŋ wən ðəɹ ɑɹ pipəl jə nid tə seɪv ɪz fulɪʃ.

Nynaeve sniffed. "I completed the weaves I needed to. I maintained my focus. Yes, I broke my calm - but I kept a cool enough head to com- plete my tasks. One should not demand calmness for the mere sake of calmness, and a prohibition on running when there are people you need to save is foolish.

"maɪ ɡoʊl ɪn ðɪs tɛst wɑz tə pɹuv ðəɾ aɪ dɪzɝv tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɛl, ðən aɪ kəɾ ɑɹɡju ðət ðə laɪvz ə ðə pipəl aɪ sɔ wɝ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ɡeɪnɪŋ ðət taɪɾəl. ɪf luzɪŋ maɪ taɪɾəl ɪz wʌt wəd bi ɹikwaɪɝd tə seɪv sʌmwʌnz laɪf - ən ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ʌðɝ kɑnsəkwɛnsəz - aɪd də ɪt. ɛvɹi taɪm. nɑt seɪvɪŋ əm wʊdn bi sɝvɪŋ ə haɪɝ ɡʊd; ɪt wəd dʒʌs bi sɛlfɪʃ."

"My goal in this test was to prove that I deserve to be Aes Sedai. Well, then I could argue that the lives of the people I saw were more important than gaining that title. If losing my title is what would be required to save someone's life - and if there were no other consequences - I'd do it. Every time. Not saving them wouldn't be serving a higher good; it would just be selfish."

bɑɹɑsinz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd wɪð æŋɡɝ. nɪneɪiv tɝn tə wɔk -  wɪð səm dɪfəkəlti - tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, wɛɹ ʃi kəd sɪɾ ɑn ə bɛntʃ ən ɹɛst. ðə wɪmən ɡæðɝd təɡɛðɝ tə spik sɔfli, ən ɛɡwin wɔkt - stɪl sɝin - oʊvɝ tə nɪneɪiv. ði æmɪɝlɪn sæt daʊn bɪsaɪd hɝ.

Barasine's eyes opened wide with anger. Nynaeve turned to walk -  with some difficulty - to the side of the room, where she could sit on a bench and rest. The women gathered together to speak softly, and Egwene walked - still serene - over to Nynaeve. The Amyrlin sat down beside her.

ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn əlaʊd tə pɑɹtɪsəpeɪɾ ɪn ðə tɛst, ən kɹieɪt səm ə ði ɪkspɪɹiənsɪz ðət tɛstəd nɪneɪiv, ðə tʃɔɪs ə ðə ɹeɪzɪŋ wəd bi ʌp tə ði ʌðɝz.

Though she had been allowed to participate in the test, and create some of the experiences that tested Nynaeve, the choice of the raising would be up to the others.

"juv æŋɡɝd ðɛm," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn kənfjuz ðɛm."

"You've angered them," Egwene said. "And confused them."

"aɪ spoʊk ðə tʃɹuθ," nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld.

"I spoke the truth," Nynaeve grumbled.

"pɝhæps," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ wɑzn spikɪŋ ə jəɹ aʊtbɝst. dʊɹɪŋ ðə tɛst, jə flaʊɾɪd ði ɔɹɾɝz jə wɝ ɡɪvən."

"Perhaps," Egwene said. "But I wasn't speaking of your outburst. During the test, you flouted the orders you were given."

"aɪ kʊdn flaʊt ðɛm. aɪ dɪdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ aɪd bɪn ɡɪvən ðɛm. aɪ. . . wɛl, æktʃəli  aɪ kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ wɑz səpoʊz tə du, bʌt nɑt ðə ɹizənz." nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪməst. "I couldn't flout them. I didn't remember that I'd been given them. I. . . well, actually I could remember what I was supposed to do, but not the reasons." Nynaeve grimaced. "That's why I broke the rules. I thought they were just arbitrary. I couldn't remember why I wasn't supposed to run, so in the face of seeing people die, it seemed silly to walk."

"ðə ɹulz ɑɹ səpoʊz tə hoʊl stʃɹɔŋli, ivən ðoʊ jə doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛm," ɛɡwin sɛd.

nɪneɪiv fɹaʊnd. "ðɛn haʊ - "

You've spent too much time in Tel'aran'rhiod. This test ... it seems to function much in the same way as the World of Dreams. What we create in our minds became your surroundings." Egwene clicked her tongue, shaking her head. "I warned them that this might be a danger. Your practice in the World of Dreams made you innately able to break the test."

nɪneɪiv dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ tə ðæt, filɪŋ sɪk. wʌɾ ɪf ʃi dɪd feɪl? biɪŋ kæst aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ naʊ, æftɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ soʊ kloʊs?

Nynaeve didn't reply to that, feeling sick. What if she did fail? Being cast out of the Tower now, after getting so close?

"aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ ɪnfɹækʃənz maɪt hɛlp ju, haʊɛvɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli.

"ðə faɪɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðæt wʌn wɑz ju, wɑzn ɪt? ði ʌðɝz doʊnt noʊ ðə pleɪs wɛl ɪnʌf tə kɹieɪɾ ɪt."

"The fight in the Two Rivers," Nynaeve said. "That one was you, wasn't it? The others don't know the place well enough to create it."

I couldn't be seen favoring you, but perhaps I shouId have put a stop to it. You did what you weren't supposed to, and that drove the others to be increasingly severe. sɹɪn lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝz. θɹi nɑdz. jukɪɝi, sin ænd-sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli - ɹoʊmændə. θɹi ʃeɪks ə ðə hɛd. ɹubɪnd, bɑɹɑsin, ləleɪn. ðət lɛft oʊnli sɹɪn. ðə dəsaɪɾɪŋ voʊt.

Saerin looked at the others. Three nods. Yukiri, Seaine and-surprisingly - Romanda. Three shakes of the head. Rubinde, Barasine, Lelaine. That left only Saerin. The deciding vote.

ðə bɹaʊn tɝn bæk tə hɝ. "nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə, aɪ dɪklɛɹ ðət juv pæs ðɪs tɛst.

nɛɹoʊli."

Narrowly."

tə ðə saɪd, ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɑft - ɔlmoʊst ɪnɔɾəbəl - saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪzd ʃid bɪn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ oʊn bɹɛθpɔɪnsɛvən

To the side, Egwene let out a soft - almost inaudible - sigh of relief Nynaeve realized she'd been holding her own breath.7

"It is done!" Rosil said, clapping her hands together. "Let no one ever speak of what has passed here. It is for us to share in silence with she who experienced it. It is done."

ðə wɪmən nɑɾəd ɪn əɡɹimənt, ivən ðoʊz u hæd voʊɾəd əɡɛns nɪneɪiv. noʊbɑdi wəd noʊ ðət nɪneɪiv hæd nɪɹli feɪld. ðeɪ hæd pɹɑbli kənfɹʌntəɾ əɹ əbaʊt ðə bɑlfaɪɝ dɝɛkli -  ɹæðɝ ðən sikɪŋ fɔɹməl pʌnɪʃmənt - kəz ə ðə tʃɹədɪʃən ə nɑt spikɪŋ ʌv wʌt hæpən ɪn ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil.

The women nodded in agreement, even those who had voted against Nynaeve. Nobody would know that Nynaeve had nearly failed. They had probably confronted her about the balefire directly -  rather than seeking formal punishment - because of the tradition of not speaking of what happened in the ter'angreal.

ɹɑsɪl klæpt əɡɛn. "nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə, jəl spɛn ðə naɪɾ ɪn pɹɛɹ ən kɑntəmpleɪʃən ə ðə bɝɾənz jəl teɪk ʌp ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ, wən jə dɑn ðə ʃɔl ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪts dʌn." ʃi klæpt ə θɝɾ ən faɪnəl taɪm.

Rosil clapped again. "Nynaeve al'Meara, you will spend the night in prayer and contemplation of the burdens you will take up on the morrow, when you don the shawl of an Aes Sedai. It is done." She clapped a third and final time.

She hustled through the dark camp of tents which sat just outside a partially built wall. The night sky was dim, with those clouds covering it, and fires burned at the perimeter of the camp. In truth, Nynaeve had been surprised to find these tents outside, rather than inside, the walls of the Black Tower. These women had been sent to bond Asha'man, as Rand had offered. But according to the guards, Egwene s envoy had been made to wait. The Asha'man had said that "others had the first choice," whatever that meant. Egwene probably knew more; she'd sent messengers back and forth with the women here, particularly to warn them about Black sisters who might be among them. Those they'd known of had vanished before the first messengers arrived.

"Child?" Myrelle said, sounding surprised. "What are you doing here?" She was an olive-skinned beauty, with long black hair and rounded curves. Nynaeve had to stop herself from reaching for her braid. It was too short now to tug. That was going to take a lot of getting used to.
