"My report is finished," Seonid said, pointedly ignoring the servant who was cleaning up porcelain shards in front of her.

"aɪ stæn baɪ maɪ ɝliɝ dɪsɪʒən," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "dilɪŋ wɪð ðə waɪt-kloʊks ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. æftɝ ðət wɪl ɡoʊ tə ændɝ, ən əl tɔk tə ɪleɪn. ɡɹeɪɾi, haʊ ɑɹ jə mænɪdʒɪŋ?"

"I stand by my earlier decision," Perrin said. "Dealing with the White-cloaks is important. After that we'll go to Andor, and I'll talk to Elayne. Grady, how are you managing?"

ðə wɛðɝɾ æʃəmən lʊkt ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ i sæɾ ɪn ɪz blæk koʊt. "aɪm fʊli ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm maɪ sɪknəs, maɪ lɔɹd, ən nild ɔlmoʊst ɪz əz wɛl."

The weathered Asha'man looked up from where he sat in his black coat. "I'm fully recovered from my sickness, my Lord, and Neald almost is as well."

"ju stɪl lʊk taɪɝd," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"You still look tired," Perrin said.

"aɪ æm," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, "bʌt bɝn mi, aɪm bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ wɑz mɛni ə deɪ ɪn ðə fil bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɛn tə ðə blæk taʊɝ."

"I am," Grady said, "but burn me, I'm better than I was many a day in the field before I went to the Black Tower."

"ɪts taɪm tə stɑɹt sɛndɪŋ səm ə ðiz ɹɛfjudʒiz wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɪð ðoʊz sɝkəlz, jə kən kip ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən lɔŋɡɝ?"

"It's time to start sending some of these refugees where they belong," Perrin said. "With those circles, you can keep a gateway open longer?"

"aɪm nɑt ɹaɪt ʃʊɹ. biɪŋ ɪn ə sɝkəl ɪz stɪl taɪɹɪŋ. meɪbi mɔɹ soʊ. bʌɾ aɪ kən meɪk mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ɡeɪtweɪz wɪð ðə hɛlp ə ðə wɪmən, waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaɪv tu wæɡənz θɹu."

"I'm not right sure. Being in a circle is still tiring. Maybe more so. But I can make much larger gateways with the help of the women, wide enough to drive two wagons through."

"ɡʊd. wɪl stɑɹt baɪ sɛndɪŋ ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi foʊk hoʊm. itʃ pɝsən wi si bæk wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ wɪl bi ə stoʊn ɔf maɪ bæk."

"Good. We'll start by sending the ordinary folk home. Each person we see back where they belong will be a stone off my back."

"æn ɪf ðeɪ doʊnt wɑnə ɡoʊ?" tɑɹn æskt. "ə lɑɾ ə ðɛm əv stɑɹɾəd ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, pɛɹɪn. ðeɪ noʊ wʌts kʌmɪŋ, ən ðeɪd ɹæðɝ feɪs ɪt hɪɹ - wɪð jə - ðən kaʊɝ ɪn ðɛɹ hoʊmz."

"And if they don't want to go?" Tarn asked. "A lot of them have started the training, Perrin. They know what's coming, and they'd rather face it here - with you - than cower in their homes."

laɪt! wɝ ðəɹ noʊ pipəl ɪn ðɪs kæmp u wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ðɛɹ fæmliz? "ʃʊɹli ðəɹ ɑɹ səm ə ðɛm u wɑnə ɡoʊ bæk."

Light! Were there no people in this camp who wanted to go back to their families? "Surely there are some of them who want to go back."

"sʌm," tɑɹn sɛd.

"Some," Tarn said.

ɹɪmɛmbɝ," feɪl sɛd, "ðə wik ən ði eɪdʒɪd wɝ sɛn əweɪ baɪ ði il."

Remember," Faile said, "the weak and the aged were sent away by the Aiel."

ɑɹɡændə nɑɾəd. "aɪv lʊkt ɪn ɑn ðiz tʃɹups. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ðə ɡætʃeɪn ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ stupɝ, ən wən ðeɪ du, ðəɹ hɑɹd. hɑɹɾ əz mɛni soʊlʒɝz aɪv noʊn."

Arganda nodded. "I've looked in on these troops. More and more of the gat'shain are coming out of their stupor, and when they do, they're hard. Hard as many soldiers I've known."

səm wɪl wɑnə tʃɛk ɑn fæmli," tɑɹn sɛd, "bʌɾ oʊnli ɪf jəl lɛɾ əm bæk. ðeɪ kən si ðət skaɪ. ðeɪ noʊ wʌts kʌmɪŋ."

Some will want to check on family," Tarn said, "but only if you'll let them back. They can see that sky. They know what's coming."

"fɔɹ naʊ, wɪl sɛn bæk ðə wʌnz ðət wɑnə ɡoʊ ən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðɛɹ hoʊmz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ kæn dil wɪð ði ʌðɝz əntɪl æftɝ aɪm dʌn wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks."

"For now, we'll send back the ones that want to go and remain in their homes," Perrin said. "I can't deal with the others until after I'm done with the Whitecloaks."

"ɛksələnt," ɡælɛn sɛɾ iɡɝli. "ju hæv ə plæn ʌv ətæk?"

"Excellent," Gallenne said eagerly. "You have a plan of attack?"

"wɛl," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "aɪ fɪɡjɝ ðəɾ ɪf ðəɹ gɑnə bi kəmpænjənəbəl ɪnʌf tə laɪn ʌp, wɪl əv əɾ əm wɪð maɪ ɑɹtʃɝz ən tʃænlɝz ən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm."

"Well," Perrin said, "I figure that if they're going to be companionable enough to line up, we'll have at them with my archers and channelers and destroy them."

"aɪ əpɹuv ə ðɪs plæn," ɡælɛn sɛd, "soʊ lɔŋ əz maɪ mɛn kən tʃɑɹdʒ tə dil wɪð ðə ɹæbəl lɛft ət ði ɛnd."

"I approve of this plan," Gallenne said, "so long as my men can charge to deal with the rabble left at the end."

"beɪlwɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɹaɪt ðə waɪtkloʊks. tɛl əm wɪl faɪɾ ən ðət ðeɪ ʃəd pɪk ə pleɪs."

"Balwer," Perrin said. "Write the Whitecloaks. Tell them we'll fight and that they should pick a place."

əz i sɛd ðə wɝdz, hi fɛlt ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɹɪlʌktəns. ɪt sim sətʃ ə weɪs tə kɪl soʊ mɛni hu kəd faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ. bʌɾ i dɪdn si ə weɪ ɝaʊn ɪt.

As he said the words, he felt a strange reluctance. It seemed such a waste to kill so many who could fight against the Shadow. But he didn't see a way around it.

beɪlwɝ nɑɾəd, smɛlɪŋ fɪɹs. wʌt hæd ðə waɪtkloʊks dʌn tə beɪlwɝ? ðə dʌsti sɛkɹətɛɹi wɑz fæsəneɪɾəd wɪð ðɛm.

Balwer nodded, smelling fierce. What had the Whitecloaks done to Balwer? The dusty secretary was fascinated with them.

ðə miɾɪŋ bɪɡæn tə bɹeɪk ʌp. pɛɹɪn stɛp tə ðə tɛns oʊpən saɪɾ ən wɑtʃt ðə sɛpɹət ɡɹups liv, æliændɝ ən ɑɹɡændə muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛɹ sɛkʃən ə ðə kæmp. feɪl wɔk bɪsaɪd bɹəleɪn; ɑdli, ðə tu wɝ tʃæɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. ðɛɹ sɛns sɛd ðeɪ wɝ æŋɡɹi, bʌt ðɛɹ wɝdz saʊndəd kəmpænjənəbəl. wʌt wɝ ðoʊz tu ʌp tə?

The meeting began to break up. Perrin stepped to the tent's open side and watched the separate groups leave, Alliandre and Arganda moving toward their section of the camp. Faile walked beside Berelain; oddly, the two were chatting together. Their scents said they were angry, but their words sounded companionable. What were those two up to?

oʊnli ə fju wɛt steɪnz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛn ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə dʒɹɑp tʃɹeɪ. wʌt wɑz ɹɔŋ wɪð meɪaɪɡdɪn? ɪɹæɾɪk bɪheɪvjɝ laɪk ðət wɑz dɪstɝbɪŋ; ɔl tu ɔfən, ɪt wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ səm mænəfɛsteɪʃən ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝ.

Only a few wet stains on the ground inside the tent remained of the dropped tray. What was wrong with Maighdin? Erratic behavior like that was disturbing; all too often, it was followed by some manifestation of the Dark One's power.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ə vɔɪs æskt, pɹɪsiɾɪd baɪ ə kwaɪət kɑf. pɛɹɪn tɝnd, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət beɪlwɝ wɑz weɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi stʊd wɪð hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɪm, lʊkɪŋ laɪk ə paɪl ə stɪks ðət tʃɪlʒɹən hæd dʒɹɛst ʌp ɪn ən oʊld ʃɝɾ ən koʊt.

"My Lord?" a voice asked, preceded by a quiet cough. Perrin turned, realizing that Balwer was waiting behind him. The secretary stood with hands clasped before him, looking like a pile of sticks that children had dressed up in an old shirt and coat.

"jɛs?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Yes?" Perrin asked.

"aɪ hæpən tə oʊvɝhɪɹ sɛvɹəl aɪɾəmz ʌv, ɑ, səm ɪntʃɹəst waɪl vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə skɑlɝz ə kɛɹhin."

"I happened to overhear several items of, ah, some interest while visiting the scholars of Cairhien."

"ju faʊn ðə səplaɪz, ɹaɪt?"

"You found the supplies, right?"

"jɛs, jɛs. aɪm kwaɪt wɛl stɑkt. pliz, ə moʊmənt. aɪ də bɪliv jəl bi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn wʌɾ aɪ oʊvɝhɝd."

"Yes, yes. I am quite well stocked. Please, a moment. I do believe you'll be interested in what I overheard."

"ɡoʊ əhɛd, ðɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd, wɔkɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən. ðə læst ə ði ʌðɝz hæd lɛft.

"Go ahead, then," Perrin said, walking back into the pavilion. The last of the others had left.

beɪlwɝ spoʊk ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs. "fɝst ɔf, maɪ lɔɹd, ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ ɪn liɡ wɪð ðə sintʃæn. ɪts kɑmən nɑlədʒ naʊ, ən aɪ wɝi ðət ðə fɔɹs əhɛɾ ʌv əs wɑz plæntəd tə - -'

Balwer spoke in a soft voice. "First off, my Lord, it appears that the Children of the Light are in league with the Seanchan. It is common knowledge now, and I worry that the force ahead of us was planted to - -'

"beɪlwɝ," pɛɹɪn ɪntɝʌptɪd, "aɪ noʊ jə heɪt ðə waɪtkloʊks, bʌt juv ɔlɹɛɾi toʊl mi ðət nuz ə hæf-dʌzən taɪmz oʊvɝ." "jɛs, bʌt - "

"Balwer," Perrin interrupted, "I know you hate the Whitecloaks, but you've already told me that news a half-dozen times over." "Yes, but - "

"nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ əbaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks," pɛɹɪn sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə hænd. "ənlɛs ɪts spəsɪfɪk nuz əbaʊt ðɪs fɔɹs əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. juv ɛni ʌv ðæt?"

"Nothing more about the Whitecloaks," Perrin said, holding up a hand. "Unless it's specific news about this force ahead of us. Do you have any of that?"

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"No, my Lord."

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn. wɑz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls jə wɑntəd tə tɛl mi?"

"All right, then. Was there anything else you wanted to tell me?"

beɪlwɝ ʃoʊd noʊ saɪnz ʌv ənɔɪəns, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd smɛl dɪsæɾɪsfækʃən. laɪt nu ðət ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd plɛnti tə ænsɝ fɔɹ, ən pɛɹɪn dɪdn bleɪm beɪlwɝ fəɹ ɪz heɪtʃɹəd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd ɡɹoʊ wiɹiɪŋ.

Balwer showed no signs of annoyance, but Perrin could smell dissatisfaction. Light knew that the Whitecloaks had plenty to answer for, and perrin didn't blame Balwer for his hatred, but it did grow wearying.

"wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ kəntɪnjud, "aɪ wəd hæzɝd ðət ðə teɪlz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑntɪŋ ə tʃɹus wɪð ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən aɪɾəl hɪɹseɪ. sɛvɹəl sɔɹsəz ɪndəkeɪt ðət hiz sud ðɛɹ liɾɝ fəɹ pis."

"Well, my Lord," Balwer continued, "I would hazard that the tales of the Dragon Reborn wanting a truce with the Seanchan are more than idle hearsay. Several sources indicate that he has sued their leader for peace."

"bʌt wʌɾ i də tə hɪz hænd?" pɛɹɪn æskt, dɪspɛlɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ɪmədʒ ə ɹænd fɹəm ɪz vɪʒən.

"But what did he do to his hand?" Perrin asked, dispelling yet another image of Rand from his vision.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"What was that, my Lord?"

"nʌθɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Nothing," Perrin said.

"ɪn ədɪʃən," beɪlwɝ sɛd, ɹitʃɪŋ ɪndə hɪz sliv, "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ən əlɑɹmɪŋ nʌmbɝ ə ðiz tʃɹævlɪŋ əmʌŋ kʌtpɝsɪz, slɪpfɪŋɝz ən fʊtpædz ɪn kɛɹhin." hi pʊld aʊɾ ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ wɪð ə skɛtʃ ə pɛɹɪnz feɪs ɑn ɪt. ðə laɪknəs wɑz əlɑɹmɪŋli ɡʊd. pɛɹɪn tʊk ðə peɪpɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"In addition," Balwer said, reaching into his sleeve, "there are an alarming number of these traveling among cutpurses, slipfingers and footpads in Cairhien." He pulled out a sheet of paper with a sketch of Perrin's face on it. The likeness was alarmingly good. Perrin took the paper, frowning.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɝdz ɑn ɪt. beɪlwɝ hændəɾ ɪm ə sɛkənd wʌn, aɪdɛntɪkəl tə ðə fɝst. ə θɝd peɪpɝ fɑloʊd, ðɪs wʌn wɪð ə pɪktʃɝ ə mæt.

There were no words on it. Balwer handed him a second one, identical to the first. A third paper followed, this one with a picture of Mat.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðiz?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Where did you get these?" Perrin asked.

"æz aɪ sɛd, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ kəntɪnjud, "ðeɪ ɑɹ biɪŋ pæst ɝaʊn ɪn sɝɾən sɝkəlz.

"As I said, my Lord," Balwer continued, "they are being passed around in certain circles.

əpɛɹənli ðəɹ ɑɹ vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ sʌmz ə mʌni pɹɑməs tə ɛniwʌn u kən pɹədus jəɹ kɔɹps, ðoʊ aɪ kəd nɑt dətɝmən u wəd bi duɪŋ ðə peɪɪŋ."

Apparently there are very large sums of money promised to anyone who can produce your corpse, though I could not determine who would be doing the paying."

"æn jə dɪskʌvɝd ðiz waɪl vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə skɑlɝz ət ɹændz skul?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"And you discovered these while visiting the scholars at Rand's school?" Perrin asked.

ðə pɪntʃ-feɪst skɹaɪb dɪspleɪd noʊ ɪmoʊʃən.

The pinch-faced scribe displayed no emotion.

"hu ɑɹ jə ɹɪli, beɪlwɝ?"

"Who are you really, Balwer?"

ə sɛkɹətɛɹi. wɪð səm mɛʒɝ ə skɪl ɪn faɪndɪŋ sikɹəts." səm mɛʒɝ? beɪlwɝ, aɪ hævən æskt æftɝ jəɹ pæst. aɪ fɪɡjɝ ə mæn dɪzɝvz tə bi eɪbəl tə stɑɹt fɹɛʃ. bʌt naʊ ðə waɪtkloʊks ɑɹ hɪɹ, ən juv səm kənɛkʃən tə ðɛm. aɪ nid tə noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz."

A secretary. With some measure of skill in finding secrets." Some measure? Balwer, I haven't asked after your past. I figure a man deserves to be able to start fresh. But now the Whitecloaks are here, and you have some connection to them. I need to know what it is."

beɪlwɝ stʊd saɪlənli fəɹ ə taɪm. ðə ɹeɪzd wɔlz ə ðə pəvɪljən ɹʌsəld.

Balwer stood silently for a time. The raised walls of the pavilion rustled.

"maɪ pɹiviəs ɛmplɔɪɝ wɑz ə mæn aɪ ɹɪspɛktɪd, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛd.

"My previous employer was a man I respected, my Lord," Balwer said.

"hi wɑz kɪl baɪ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. səm əmʌŋ əm meɪ ɹɛk-ɑɡnaɪz mi."

"He was killed by the Children of the Light. Some among them may rec-ognize me."

"ju wɝ ə spaɪ fəɹ ðɪs pɝsən?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You were a spy for this person?" Perrin asked.

beɪlwɝz lɪps tɝn daʊn dɪstɪŋkli. hi spoʊk mɔɹ sɔfli. "aɪ mɪɹli hæv ə maɪn fəɹ ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ fæks, maɪ lɔɹd."

Balwer's lips turned down distinctly. He spoke more softly. "I merely have a mind for remembering facts, my Lord."

"jɛs, juv ɡɑɾ ə vɛɹi ɡʊd maɪn fəɹ ɪt. jəɹ sɝvəs ɪz jusfəl tə mi, beɪlwɝ. aɪm oʊnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɛl jə ðæt. aɪm ɡlæd jəɹ hɪɹ."

"Yes, you've got a very good mind for it. Your service is useful to me, Balwer. I'm only trying to tell you that. I'm glad you're here."

ðə mæn smɛl plizd. "ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd, ɪts ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ tə wɝk fəɹ sʌmwʌn u dʌzn si maɪ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əz sɪmpli ə minz ə bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ əɹ kɑmpɹəmaɪzɪŋ ðoʊz ɝaʊn hɪm."

The man smelled pleased. "If I may say, my Lord, it is refreshing to work for someone who doesn't see my information as simply a means of betraying or compromising those around him."

"wɛl, bi ðəɾ əz ɪt meɪ, aɪ ʃəd pɹɑbli stɑɹt peɪɪŋ jə bɛɾɝ" pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Well, be that as it may, I should probably start paying you better" Perrin said.

ðət ɡeɪv beɪlwɝ ə pænɪk sɛnt. "ðæt woʊn bi nɛsəsɛɹi."

That gave Balwer a panicked scent. "That won't be necessary."

"ju kəd dɪmæn haɪ weɪdʒəz fɹəm ɛni nʌmbɝ ə lɔɹdz əɹ mɝtʃəns!"

"You could demand high wages from any number of lords or merchants!"

"pɛɾi mɛn ə noʊ kɑnsəkwəns," beɪlwɝ sɛd wɪð ə twɪtʃ ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz.

"Petty men of no consequence," Balwer said with a twitch of his fingers.

"jɛs, bʌɾ aɪ stɪl θɪŋk jə ʃəd bi peɪd mɔɹ. ɪts sɪmpəl sɛns. ɪf jə haɪɝ ən əpɹɛntəs blæksmɪθ fəɹ jəɹ fɔɹdʒ ən doʊn peɪ hɪm wɛl ɪnʌf, hɪl ɪmpɹɛs jəɹ ɹɛɡjəlɝ kʌstəmɝz, ðən oʊpən ə nu fɔɹdʒ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit ðə moʊmən i kən əfɔɹd tə."

"Yes, but I still think you should be paid more. It's simple sense. If you hire an apprentice blacksmith for your forge and don't pay him well enough, he'll impress your regular customers, then open a new forge across the street the moment he can afford to."

"ɑ, bʌt jə də nɑt si, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛd. "mʌni minz nʌθɪŋ tə mi. ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən -  ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. fæks ən dɪskʌvɝiz . . . ðeɪ ɑɹ laɪk nʌɡəts ʌv ɡoʊld. aɪ kəd ɡɪv ðət ɡoʊl tə ə kɑmən bæŋkɝ tə meɪk kɔɪnz, bʌɾ aɪ pɹəfɝ tə ɡɪv ɪt tə ðə mæstɝ kɹæfsmən tə meɪk sʌmθɪŋ ə bjuɾi.

"Ah, but you do not see, my Lord," Balwer said. "Money means nothing to me. The information -  that is what is important. Facts and discoveries . . . they are like nuggets of gold. I could give that gold to a common banker to make coins, but I prefer to give it to the master craftsman to make something of beauty.

"pliz, maɪ lɔɹd, lemi ɹɪmeɪn ə sɪmpəl sɛkɹətɛɹi. jə si, wʌn ə ði iziəst weɪz tə tɛl ɪf sʌmwʌn ɪz nɑt wʌɾ i simz ɪz tə tʃɛk ɪz weɪdʒəz." hi tʃʌkəld. "aɪv ənkʌvɝd mɔɹ ðən wʌn əsæsən əɹ spaɪ ðət weɪ, jɛs aɪ hæv. noʊ peɪ ɪz niɾəd. ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə wɝk wɪð jə ɪz ɪts oʊn peɪmənt."

"Please, my Lord, let me remain a simple secretary. You see, one of the easiest ways to tell if someone is not what he seems is to check his wages." He chuckled. "I've uncovered more than one assassin or spy that way, yes I have. No pay is needed. The opportunity to work with you is its own payment."

pɛɹɪn ʃɹʌɡd, bʌt nɑɾəd, ən beɪlwɝ wɪθdʒɹu. pɛɹɪn stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə pəvɪljən, stoʊɪŋ ðə pɪktʃɝz ɪn ɪz pɑkət. ðeɪ dɪstɝb hɪm. hid bɛt ðiz pɪktʃɝz wɝ ɪn ændɝ, tu, pleɪs baɪ ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

Perrin shrugged, but nodded, and Balwer withdrew. Perrin stepped out of the pavilion, stowing the pictures in his pocket. They disturbed him. He'd bet these pictures were in Andor, too, placed by the Forsaken.

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i wɑz gɑnə niɾ ən ɑɹmi tə kip hɪmsɛlf seɪf. ɪt wɑz ə dɪstɝbɪŋ θɔt.

For the first time, he found himself wondering if he was going to need an army to keep himself safe. It was a disturbing thought.

ðə weɪv ə bɛstʃəl tʃɹɑləks sɝdʒd oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə ðə hɪl, oʊvɝɹʌnɪŋ ðə læst ə ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz. ðeɪ ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən haʊld, θɪk-fɪŋɡɝd hænz tɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɑɹk sɑldəiən sɔɪl ən klʌtʃɪŋ sɔɹdz, hʊk spɪɹz, hæmɝz, klʌbz ən ʌðɝ wɪkəd wɛpənz. spɪɾəl dʒɹɪp fɹəm tʌsk lɪps ɑn sʌm, waɪl ɑn ʌðɝz waɪd, tu-hjumən aɪz stɛɹɾ aʊt fɹəm bi-.haɪnd wɪkəd biks.

The wave of bestial Trollocs surged over the top of the hill, overrunning the last of the fortifications. They grunted and howled, thick-fingered hands tearing at the dark Saldaean soil and clutching swords, hooked spears, hammers, clubs and other wicked weapons. Spittle dripped from tusked lips on some, while on others wide, too-human eyes stared out from be-.hind wicked beaks.

ðɛɹ blæk ɑɹmɝ wɑz dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð spaɪks.

Their black armor was decorated with spikes.

ɪɾɝɑldiz mɛn stʊd stʃɹɔŋ wɪð ɪm ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə bæk sloʊp ə ðə hɪlsaɪd. hi hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə loʊɝ kæmp tə dɪsbæn ən ɹitʃɹiɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ kəd tə ðə saʊθ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk. minwaɪl, ði ɑɹmi hæd ɹitʃɹiɾəd fɹəm ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz. hi heɪɾəd tə sɝɛndɝ ðə haɪ ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ɡɛɾɪŋ pʊʃt daʊn ðət stip hɪl dʊɹɪŋ ən əsɔlt wʊɾə bɪn dɛdli. hi hæd ɹum tə fɔl bæk, soʊ hid juz ɪt, naʊ ðət ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz wɝ lɔst. hi pəzɪʃən ɪz fɔɹsɪz dʒʌst ət ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl, nɪɹ wɛɹ ðə loʊɝ kæmp hæd wʌns bɪn. ðə dəmɑni soʊlʒɝz wɔɹ stil kæps ən hæd sɛt ðɛɹ fɔɹtin-fʊt paɪks wɪð bʌts ɪn ðə dɝt, hoʊldɪŋ əm fəɹ mɔɹ stəbɪlɪɾi, stil pɔɪns təwɔɹd ðə taʊɝɪŋ weɪv ə tʃɹɑləks. ə klæsɪk dɪfɛnsɪv pəzɪʃən: θɹi ɹæŋks ə pɪkmɛn ən ʃilmən, paɪks slæntəd təwɔɹd ðə tɑp ə ðə sloʊp.

Ituralde's men stood strong with him at the bottom of the back slope of the hillside. He had ordered the lower camp to disband and retreat as far as they could to the south along the riverbank. Meanwhile, the army had retreated from the fortifications. He hated to surrender the high ground, but getting pushed down that steep hill during an assault would have been deadly. He had room to fall back, so he'd use it, now that the fortifications were lost. He positioned his forces just at the base of the hill, near where the lower camp had once been. The Domani soldiers wore steel caps and had set their fourteen-foot pikes with butts in the dirt, holding them for more stability, steel points toward the towering wave of Trollocs. A classic defensive position: three ranks of pikemen and shieldmen, pikes slanted toward the top of the slope.

wən ðə fɝst ɹæŋk ə paɪks kɪld ə tʃɹɑliɑk, ðeɪd fɔl bæk ən pʊl ðɛɹ wɛpənz fɹi, lɛɾɪŋ ðə sɛkən ɹæŋk stɛp fɔɹwɝd tə kɪl. ə sloʊ, kɛɹfəl ɹitʃɹit, ɹæŋk baɪ ɹæŋk. ə dʌbəl ɹoʊ ʌv ɑɹtʃɝz bɪhaɪn bɪɡæn lusɪŋ æɹoʊz, slæmɪŋ weɪv æftɝ weɪv ʌp ɪndə ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, dʒɹɑpɪŋ bɑɾiz daʊn ðə sloʊp. ðoʊz ɹoʊld, səm stɪl skɹimɪŋ, spɹeɪɪŋ dɑɹk blʌd. ə lɑɹdʒɝ nʌmbɝ kəntɪnjud daʊn, oʊvɝ ðɛɹ bɹʌðɝz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ət ðə pɪkmɛn.

When the first rank of pikes killed a Trolioc, they'd fall back and pull their weapons free, letting the second rank step forward to kill. A slow, careful retreat, rank by rank. A double row of archers behind began loosing arrows, slamming wave after wave up into the Shadowspawn, dropping bodies down the slope. Those rolled, some still screaming, spraying dark blood. A larger number continued down, over their brothers, trying to get at the pikemen.

ən iɡəl-hɛɾəd tʃɹɑliɑk daɪɾ ɑn ə paɪk ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪɾɝɑldi. ðəɹ wɝ tʃɪps əlɔŋ ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə θɪŋz bik, ən ɪts hɛd - sɛt wɪð pɹɛɾətɔɹi aɪz - sæɾ ətɑp ə bʊl-laɪk nɛk, ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fɛðɝz koʊɾəd wɪð səm kaɪndə dɑɹk, ɔɪli sʌbstəns. ðə mɑnstɝ skɹitʃt əz ɪt daɪd, vɔɪs loʊ ən oʊnli feɪnli eɪviən, sʌmhaʊ fɔɹmɪŋ ɡʌɾɝəl saʊnz ɪn ðə tʃɹɑliɑk læŋɡwədʒ.

An eagle-headed Trolioc died on a pike in front of Ituralde. There were chips along the edges of the thing's beak, and its head - set with predatory eyes - sat atop a bull-like neck, the edge of the feathers coated with some kind of dark, oily substance. The monster screeched as it died, voice low and only faintly avian, somehow forming guttural sounds in the Trolioc language.

"hoʊld!" ɪɾɝɑldi kɔld, tɝnɪŋ ən tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs daʊn ðə laɪn ə pɪkmɛn. "kip ðə fɔɹmeɪʃən, bɝn ju!"

"Hold!" Ituralde called, turning and trotting his horse down the line of pikemen. "Keep the formation, burn you!"

ðə tʃɹɑləks sɝdʒ daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd, daɪɪŋ ɑn ðoʊz paɪks. ɪt wəd bi ə tɛmpɝɛɹi ɹipɹiv.

The Trollocs surged down the hillside, dying on those pikes. It would be a temporary reprieve.

ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni tʃɹɑləks, ən ivən ə ɹoʊteɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɪpəl paɪk laɪn wəd bi oʊvɝwɛlmd. ðɪs wɑz ə dɪleɪɪŋ tæktɪk. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz tʃɹups bɪɡæn ðɛɹ ɹitʃɹit. wʌns ðə laɪnz hæd wikənd, ði æʃəmən wəɾ əsum ðə bɝɾən ə dɪfɛns, baɪɪŋ taɪm fəɹ ðə pɪkmɛn tə ɹitʃɹit.

There were too many Trollocs, and even a rotating triple pike line would be overwhelmed. This was a delaying tactic. Behind them, the rest of his troops began their retreat. Once the lines had weakened, the Asha'man would assume the burden of defense, buying time for the pikemen to retreat.

ɪf ði æʃəmən kəd mænədʒ ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ. hid pʊʃt əm hɑɹd. meɪbi tu hɑɹd. hi dɪdnt noʊ ðɛɹ lɪməts ðə weɪ hi dɪd fəɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi tʃɹups. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ eɪbəl tə bɹeɪk ðə tʃɹɑliɑk ədvæns, hɪz ɑɹmi wəd fɔl bæk saʊθwɝd. ðət ɹitʃɹit wəd teɪk əm pæs ðə seɪfti ʌv mɛɹədɑn, bʌt ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi əlaʊɾ ɪn. ðoʊz ɪnsaɪd hæd ɹɪbʌft ɔl ɪɾɝɑldiz ətɛmps ət kəmjunəkeɪʃən. "wi də nɑɾ əbɛɾ ɪnveɪɾɝz" hæd bɪn ðə ɹɪplaɪ itʃ taɪm. blʌɾi fulz.

If the Asha'man could manage the strength. He'd pushed them hard. Maybe too hard. He didn't know their limits the way he did for ordinary troops. If they were able to break the Trolioc advance, his army would fall back southward. That retreat would take them past the safety of Maradon, but they would not be allowed in. Those inside had rebuffed all Ituralde's attempts at communication. "We do not abet invaders" had been the reply each time. Bloody fools.

wɛl, ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd laɪkli fɔɹm ʌp ɝaʊn mɛɹədɑn fəɹ ə səsteɪn sidʒ, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪz mɛn taɪm tə fɔl bæk tə ə mɔɹ dɪfɛnsəbəl pəzɪʃən.

Well, the Trollocs would likely form up around Maradon for a sustained siege, giving Ituralde and his men time to fall back to a more defensible position.

"hoʊld!" ɪɾɝɑldi kɔld əɡɛn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ pæst ən ɛɹiə wɛɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk pɹɛs wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ ɹɪzʌls. ətɑp wʌn ə ðə hɪltɑp fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz ə pæk ʌv wʊlf-hɛɾəd tʃɹɑləks lɝkt, wɛɹi, waɪl ðɛɹ kəmpænjənz tʃɑɹdʒ daʊn bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. "ɑɹtʃɝz!" ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ.

"Hold!" Ituralde called again, riding past an area where the Trolloc press was beginning to show results. Atop one of the hilltop fortifications a pack of wolf-headed Trollocs lurked, wary, while their companions charged down before them. "Archers!" Ituralde said, pointing.

ə vɑli ʌv æɹoʊz fɑloʊd, spɹeɪɪŋ ðə wʊlf-hɛɾəd tʃɹɑləks, əɹ "maɪnz" əz ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn ɪn ɪɾɝɑldiz ɑɹmi hæd stɑɹɾəd kɔlɪŋ ðɛm. tʃɹɑləks hæd ðɛɹ oʊn bænz ən ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, bʌɾ ɪz mɛn ɔfən ɹəfɝd tə ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz baɪ ðə fitʃɝz ðeɪ dɪspleɪd. "hɔɹnz" fəɹ ɡoʊts, "biks" fəɹ hɔks, "ɑɹmz" fəɹ bɛɹz. ðoʊz wɪð ðə hɛdz ʌv wʊlvz wɝ ɔfən əmʌŋ ðə mɔɹ ɪntɛlədʒənt;

A volley of arrows followed, spraying the wolf-headed Trollocs, or "Minds" as the Dragonsworn in Ituralde's army had started calling them. Trollocs had their own bands and organization, but his men often referred to individuals by the features they displayed. "Horns" for goats, "Beaks" for hawks, "Arms" for bears. Those with the heads of wolves were often among the more intelligent;

səm sɑldəiənz kleɪm tə hæv hɝɾ əm spikɪŋ ðə hjumən læŋɡwədʒ tə bɑɹɡən wɪð əɹ tʃɹɪk ðɛɹ əpoʊnəns.

some Saldaeans claimed to have heard them speaking the human language to bargain with or trick their opponents.

ɪɾɝɑldi nu mʌtʃ əbaʊt tʃɹɑləks naʊ. jə niɾəd tə noʊ jəɹ ɛnəmi. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðəɹ wɑz hjudʒ vɝaɪəɾi ɪn tʃɹɑlɑk ɪntɛlədʒəns ən pɝsənælɪɾi. ən ðəɹ wɝ mɛni tʃɹɑləks u ʃɛɹd fɪzɪkəl ætʃɹəbjuts fɹəm vɛɹiəs ɡɹups. ɪɾɝɑldi swɔɹ hid sin wʌn twɪstəɾ əbɑməneɪʃən wɪð ðə fɛðɝz ʌv ə hɔk bʌt ðə hɔɹnz ʌv ə ɡoʊt.

Ituralde knew much about Trollocs now. You needed to know your enemy. Unfortunately, there was huge variety in Trolloc intelligence and personality. And there were many Trollocs who shared physical attributes from various groups. Ituralde swore he'd seen one twisted abomination with the feathers of a hawk but the horns of a goat.

ðə tʃɹɑləks ətɑp ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ði æɹoʊz. ə lɑɹdʒ pæk ə hʌlkɪŋ bists bɪhaɪnd ʃʌvd əm daʊn ðə hɪl wɪð ə ɹɔɹ. tʃɹɑləks wɝ kaʊɝdli θɪŋz, nɔɹməli, ənlɛs hʌŋɡɹi, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɪpt ɪndə ə fɹɛnzi, ðeɪ fɔt wɛl.

The Trollocs atop the fortification tried to get out of the way of the arrows. A large pack of hulking beasts behind shoved them down the hill with a roar. Trollocs were cowardly things, normally, unless hungry, but if they were whipped into a frenzy, they fought well.

ðə feɪdz wəd fɑloʊ ðɪs ɪnɪʃəl weɪv. wʌns ði ɑɹtʃɝz wɝ aʊɾ ʌv æɹoʊz, ən tʃɹɑləks hæd sɔfən ðə mɛn bɪloʊ. ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdn lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðæt.

The Fades would follow this initial wave. Once the archers were out of arrows, and Trollocs had softened the men below. Ituralde didn't look forward to that.

laɪt, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt. aɪ hoʊp aɪv kən aʊtʃɹʌn ðɛm. ði æʃəmən weɪɾəd ɪn ðə dɪstəns fəɹ ɪz ɔɹɾɝ. hi wɪʃt i hæɾ əm kloʊsɝ. bʌɾ i kʊdn ti ɹɪsk ɪt. ðeɪ wɝ tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt ən æsɛt tə luz tə ə stʃɹeɪ æɹoʊ.

Light, Ituralde thought. I hope ive can outrun them. The Asha'man waited in the distance for his order. He wished he had them closer. But he couldn t risk it. They were too important an asset to lose to a stray arrow.

hoʊpfəli, ðə fɹʌn ɹæŋks ə tʃɹɑləks wəd bi səvɪɹli bæɾɝd baɪ ðə pɪkmɛn, ðɛɹ kɑɹkəsɪz twɪstəɾ ən bæŋkt əɡɛns ðə paɪks - -æn ðə tʃɹɑləks bɪhaɪn stʌmbəlɪŋ ən fɔlɪŋ əɡɛns ðɛɹ oʊn blʌɾi ɹɛmnəns. ɪɾɝɑldiz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sɑldəiənz wəd ɹaɪɾ əz ə hæɹiɪŋ fɔɹs əɾ ɛni hu ɡɑt θɹu ði æʃəmən blæsts. ðən ðə pɪkmɛn ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə dʒɹɔ bæk ən fɑloʊ ðə ɹɛst ə ði ɑɹmi ɪn ɹitʃɹit. wʌns pæs mɛɹədɑn, ðeɪ kəd juz ɡeɪtweɪz tə fɔl bæk tə hɪz nɛks tʃoʊzən pəzɪʃən, ə fɔɹəstəd pæs səm tɛn liɡz saʊθ.

Hopefully, the front ranks of Trollocs would be severely battered by the pikemen, their carcasses twisted and banked against the pikes - -and the Trollocs behind stumbling and falling against their own bloody remnants. Ituralde's remaining Saldaeans would ride as a harrying force at any who got through the Asha'man blasts. Then the pikemen should be able to draw back and follow the rest of the army in retreat. Once past Maradon, they could use gateways to fall back to his next chosen position, a forested pass some ten leagues south.

hɪz mɛn ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp. ʃʊd. laɪt, bʌɾ i heɪɾəd biɪŋ fɔɹs tə kəmæn ə tu-fæst ɹitʃɹit laɪk ðɪs.

His men should be able to escape. Should. Light, but he hated being forced to command a too-fast retreat like this.

steɪ fɝm, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə ɹaɪɾ ən kɔl aʊt ði ɔɹɾɝ tə hoʊld. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðət ðeɪ hɪɹ ɪz vɔɪs. ðət bɔɪ ɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hɪl kip bɪs pɹɑməsəz.

Stay firm, he told himself, continuing to ride and call out the order to hold. It was important that they hear his voice. That boy is the Dragon Reborn, He'll keep bis promises.

"maɪ lɔɹd!" ə vɔɪs kɔld. ɪɾɝɑldiz ɡɑɹd splɪt tə lɛɾ ə jʌŋ bɔɪ ɹaɪɾ ʌp, pæntɪŋ. "maɪ lɔɹd, ɪts lutɛnən lɪdʒɹɪn!"

"My Lord!" a voice called. Ituralde's guard split to let a young boy ride up, panting. "My Lord, it's Lieutenant Lidrin!"

"hiz fɔlən?" ɪɾɝɑldi dɪmændəd.

"He's fallen?" Ituralde demanded.

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. hiz . . ." ðə bɔɪ lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ɪn ðə paɪk laɪn nɪɹbaɪ, ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ bʌlʒɪŋ fɔɹwɝd təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹɑlɑk weɪv, ɹæðɝ ðən fɔlɪŋ bæk.

"No, my Lord. He's . . ." The boy looked over his shoulder. In the pike line nearby, the soldiers were bulging forward toward the Trolloc wave, rather than falling back.

"wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt?" ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, hilɪŋ dɔnwiv ɪndə moʊʃən. ðə waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ ɡæləp fɔɹwɝd, ɪɾɝɑldiz ɡɑɹɾ ən ðə jʌŋ mɛsənʒɝ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪm ɪn ə θʌndɝ ə hʊvz.

"What in the Light?" Ituralde said, heeling Dawnweave into motion. The white gelding galloped forward, Ituralde's guard and the young messenger joining him in a thunder of hooves.

hi kəd hɪɹ lɪdʒɹɪnz jɛlz dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɔɹ ə ðə bæɾəlfild. ðə jʌŋ dəmɑni ɔfəsɝ wɑz aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə paɪk laɪnz, ətækɪŋ ðə tʃɹoʊl-lɑks wɪð sɔɹɾ ən ʃild, bɛloʊɪŋ. lɪdʒɹɪnz mɛn hæd pʊʃt θɹu tə dɪfɛn hɪm, livɪŋ ðə pɪkmɛn kənfjuzd ən dɪsɔɹiɛntɪd.

He could hear Lidrin's yells despite the roar of the battlefield. The young Domani officer was out in front of the pike lines, attacking the Trol-locs with sword and shield, bellowing. Lidrin's men had pushed through to defend him, leaving the pikemen confused and disoriented.

"lɪdʒɹɪn, jə ful." ɪɾɝɑldi ɹeɪn ɪz hɔɹs tə ə hɔlt.

"Lidrin, you fool." Ituralde reined his horse to a halt.

"kʌm!" lɪdʒɹɪn bɛloʊd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks. hi læf laʊdli, vɔɪs hæf-mæd, feɪs splæɾɝd wɪð blʌd. "kʌm! əl feɪs jə ɔl! maɪ sɔɹd θɝsts!"

"Come!" Lidrin bellowed, raising his sword up before the Trollocs. He laughed loudly, voice half-mad, face splattered with blood. "Come! I will face you all! My sword thirsts!"

"lɪdʒɹɪn!" ɪɾɝɑldi skɹimd. "lɪdʒɹɪn!"

"Lidrin!" Ituralde screamed. "Lidrin!"

ðə mæn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz aɪz wɝ waɪd wɪð ə kɹeɪz kaɪndə ɡli. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ, ɪn ði aɪz ə soʊlʒɝz u fɔt tu lɔŋ, tu hɑɹd. "wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, ɹoʊɾəl,"

The man glanced over his shoulder. His eyes were wide with a crazed kind of glee. Ituralde had seen it before, in the eyes of soldiers who fought too long, too hard. "We're going to die, Rodel,"

lɪdʒɹɪn kɔld. "ðɪs weɪ, aɪ ɡɛt tə teɪk əm wɪð mi! wʌn əɹ tu ət list! dʒɔɪn mi!"

Lidrin called. "This way, I get to take them with me! One or two at least! Join me!"

"lɪdʒɹɪn, ɡɛt bæk hɪɹ ən - "

"Lidrin, get back here and - "

ðə mæn ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm, tɝnɪŋ bæk ən pɹɛsɪŋ fɔɹwɝd.

The man ignored him, turning back and pressing forward.

'ɡɛɾ ɪz mɛn bæk hɪɹ," ɪɾɝɑldi jɛld, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ. "kloʊz ðə paɪk ɹæŋks! kwɪkli. wi kænt . . ."

'Get his men back here," Ituralde yelled, gesturing. "Close the pike ranks! Quickly. We can't . . ."

ðə tʃɹɑləks sɝdʒ fɔɹwɝd. lɪdʒɹɪn fɛl ɪn ə spɹeɪ ʌv blʌd, læfɪŋ. hɪz mɛn wɝ tu stʃɹɔŋli pɹɛst, ən ðeɪ splɪt daʊn ðə mɪɾəl. ðə pɪkmɛn ɹisɛt ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌɾ ə fɪst ə tʃɹɑləks kɹæʃt ɪndə ðɛm. səm tʃɹɑləks fɛl.

The Trollocs surged forward. Lidrin fell in a spray of blood, laughing. His men were too strongly pressed, and they split down the middle. The pikemen reset themselves, but a fist of Trollocs crashed into them. Some Trollocs fell.

moʊs dɪdnt.

Most didn't.

ðə nɪɹbaɪ kɹitʃɝz skɹitʃt ən haʊld ət siɪŋ ðə hoʊl ɪn ðə dɪfɛnsəz. ðeɪ keɪm, skɹæmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ bɑɾiz ət ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl, θɹoʊɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ət ðə pɪkmɛn.

The nearby creatures screeched and howled at seeing the hole in the defenses. They came, scrambling over bodies at the base of the hill, throwing themselves at the pikemen.

ɪɾɝɑldi kɝst, ðən pʊʃt dɔnwiv fɔɹwɝd. ɪn wɔɹ, əz ɪn fɑɹm-ɪŋ, jə səmtaɪmz hæd tə stɛp ɪn ən ɡɛt ni-dip ɪn ðə mʌk. hi bɛloʊɾ əz i kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks. hɪz ɡɑɹd ɹoʊɾ ɪn ɝaʊn hɪm, kloʊzɪŋ ðə ɡæp. ði ɛɹ bɪkeɪm ə kɹæʃɪŋ tɛmpəst ə mɛɾəl ɑn mɛɾəl ən ɡɹʌns ə peɪn.

Ituralde cursed, then pushed Dawnweave forward. In war, as in farm-ing, you sometimes had to step in and get knee-deep in the muck. He bellowed as he crashed into the Trollocs. His guard rode in around him, closing the gap. The air became a crashing tempest of metal on metal and grunts of pain.

dɔnwiv snɔɹɾɪd ən dænst əz ɪɾɝɑldi læʃt aʊt wɪð ɪz sɔɹd. ðə wɔɹhɔɹs dɪslaɪk biɪŋ soʊ kloʊs tə ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, bʌɾ i wɑz wɛl tʃɹeɪnd, ə ɡɪft fɹəm wʌn ə bæʃɪɹz mɛn. hi hæd kleɪm ðəɾ ə dʒɛnɝəl ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz niɾəd ən ænəməl u hæd fɔt tʃɹɑləks bɪfɔɹ.

Dawnweave snorted and danced as Ituralde lashed out with his sword. The warhorse disliked being so close to the Shadowspawn, but he was well trained, a gift from one of Bashere's men. He had claimed that a general on the Borderlands needed an animal who had fought Trollocs before.

ɪɾɝɑldi blɛsɪd ðət soʊlʒɝ naʊ.

Ituralde blessed that soldier now.

ðə faɪɾɪŋ wɑz bɹuɾəl. ðə liɾɪŋ ɹæŋk ə pɪkmɛn, ən ðoʊz bɪhaɪnd, bɪɡæn bʌklɪŋ. ɪɾɝɑldi bɹifli hɝɾ æŋkɑɹz vɔɪs teɪkɪŋ kəmænd, skɹimɪŋ ət ðə mɛn tə ɡɛt bæk ɪndə laɪn. hi saʊndəd fɹæntɪk. ðət wɑz bæd.

The fighting was brutal. The leading rank of pikemen, and those behind, began buckling. Ituralde briefly heard Ankaer's voice taking command, screaming at the men to get back into line. He sounded frantic. That was bad.

ɪɾɝɑldi swʌŋ, duɪŋ hɛɹən ɑn ðə stʌmp - ə hɔɹsbæk sɔɹd fɔɹm - ən teɪkɪŋ ə bʊl-hɛɾəd tʃɹɑlɑk əkɹɔs ðə θɹoʊt. ə spɹeɪ ʌv fɛɾəd bɹaʊnɪʃ blʌd spɝɾɪd fɔɹθ, ən ðə kɹitʃɝ fɛl bæk əɡɛnst ə bɔɹ-hɛɾəd mɑnstɝ. ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd stændɝd - dɪpɪktɪŋ ə ɡoʊts skʌl wɪð ə faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪt - ɹoʊz ətɑp ðə hɪl. ðə sɪmbəl ə ðə ɡɑblɪn bænd.

Ituralde swung, doing Heron on the Stump - a horseback sword form - and taking a bull-headed Trolloc across the throat. A spray of fetid brownish blood spurted forth, and the creature fell back against a boar-headed monster. A large red standard - depicting a goat's skull with a fire burning behind it - rose atop the hill. The symbol of the Ghob'hlin Band.

ɪɾɝɑldi tɝn ɪz hɔɹs, dænsɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ə wɪkəɾ æks bloʊ, ðən ɝdʒd ɪz maʊn fɔɹwɝd, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks saɪd. ɝaʊn hɪm, wɛlbɝn ən lɛhaɪnən - tu ʌv ɪz bɛst - daɪɾ əz ðeɪ dɪfɛndəɾ ɪz flæŋk. laɪt bɝn ðə tʃɹɑləks!

Ituralde turned his horse, dancing out of the way of a wicked axe blow, then urged his mount forward, driving his sword into the Trollocs side. Around him, Whelborn and Lehynen - two of his best - died as they defended his flank. Light burn the Trollocs!

ði ɪntaɪɝ laɪn wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt. hi ən ɪz mɛn wɝ tu fju, bʌt moʊst ə hɪz fɔɹsɪz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pʊl bæk. noʊ, noʊ, noʊ! ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛkstʃɹəkeɪt hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ðə bæɾəl ən teɪk oʊvɝ ðə kəmænd. bʌɾ ɪf i pʊl bæk, ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd bɹeɪk θɹu.

The entire line was breaking apart. He and his men were too few, but most of his forces had already pulled back. No, no, no! Ituralde thought, trying to extricate himself from the battle and take over the command. But if he pulled back, the Trollocs would break through.

hiɾ əv tə ɹɪsk ɪt. hi wɑz ɹɛɾi fəɹ pɹɑbləmz laɪk ðɪs.

He'd have to risk it. He was ready for problems like this.

ə tʃɹʌmpət saʊndəd ɹitʃɹit.

A trumpet sounded retreat.

ɪɾɝɑldi fɹoʊz, lɪsnɪŋ wɪð hɔɹɝ tə ðə hɔntəd saʊn ɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bæɾəlfild. ðə hɔɹnz wɝn səpoʊz tə bloʊ ənlɛs hi, əɹ ə mɛmbɝ ə hɪz ɡɑɹd, ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ pɝsənəli! ɪt wɑz tu sun, fɑɹ tu sun.

Ituralde froze, listening with horror to the haunted sound rolling across the battlefield. The horns weren't supposed to blow unless he, or a member of his guard, gave the order personally! It was too soon, far too soon.

səm ə ði ʌðɝ tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz hɝd ðə kɔl ən tʊk ɪɾ ʌp, ðoʊ ʌðɝz dɪd nɑt. ðeɪ kəd si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz fɑɹ tu sun. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðət wɑz wɝs. ɪt mɛn ðət hæf ə ðə pɪkmɛn bɪɡæn tə pʊl bæk waɪl ði ʌðɝ hæf hɛl ðɛɹ pəzɪʃən.

Some of the other trumpeters heard the call and took it up, though others did not. They could see that it was far too soon. Unfortunately, that was worse. It meant that half of the pikemen began to pull back while the other half held their position.

ðə laɪnz ɝaʊn ɪɾɝɑldi bɝst, mɛn skæɾɝɪŋ əz ðə tʃɹɑləks swɔɹmd oʊvɝ ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ə dɪzæstɝ, əz bæɾ ə dɪzæstɝ əz ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn pɑɹɾ ʌv. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz fɛlt lɪmp.

The lines around Ituralde burst, men scattering as the Trollocs swarmed over them. It was a disaster, as bad a disaster as Ituralde had ever been part of. His fingers felt limp.

ɪf wi fɔl, ʃæɾoʊzpɔn dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɑɹæd dumən. ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɔɹd, jæŋkɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɪz hɔɹs ən ɡæləpɪŋ bæk əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɝdʒɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ mɛmbɝz ə hɪz ɡɑɹd fɑloʊd.

If we fall, Shadowspawn destroy Arad Doman. Ituralde roared, yanking on the reins of his horse and galloping back away from the surging Trollocs. The remaining members of his guard followed.

"hɛlmk ən kjutʃɹɪs," ɪɾɝɑldi jɛl tə tu ʌv ɪz mɛn, stɝɾi, lɔŋɡlɪm dəmɑni. "ɡɛt tə dɝəmz kævəlɹi ən tɛl əm tə ətæk ðə sɛntɝ əz sun əz ən oʊpənɪŋ əpɪɹz! kɑpɝ, hɛd tə əlɪnz kævəlɹi. ɔɹɾɝ ɪm tə əsɔl ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑn ði istɝn flæŋk. sɔɹɛntɪn, ɡoʊ tə ðoʊz æʃəmən! aɪ wɑn ðə tʃɹɑləks tə ɡoʊ ʌp ɪn fleɪm!"

"Helmke and Cutaris," Ituralde yelled to two of his men, sturdy, longlimbed Domani. "Get to Durhem's cavalry and tell them to attack the center as soon as an opening appears! Kappre, head to Alin's cavalry. Order him to assault the Trollocs on the eastern flank. Sorrentin, go to those Asha'man! I want the Trollocs to go up in flame!"

ðə hɔɹsmən ɡæləpt ɔf. ɪɾɝɑldi ɹoʊd wɛstwɝd, tə ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə pɪkmɛn wɝ stɪl hoʊldɪŋ. hi stɑɹɾəd tə ɹæli wʌn ə ðə bæk ɹæŋks ən bɹɪŋ ɪt tə ðə bʌlʒɪŋ sɛkʃən. hi ɔlmoʊs hæɾ ɪt wɝkɪŋ. bʌt ðən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl keɪm, slaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹæŋks laɪk sneɪks, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ wɪð ɔɪli spid, ən ə flaɪɾ ə dʒɹæɡkɝ dɪsɛndəd.

The horsemen galloped off. Ituralde rode westward, to the place where the pikemen were still holding. He started to rally one of the back ranks and bring it to the bulging section. He almost had it working. But then the Myrddraal came, sliding through the Trolloc ranks like snakes, striking with oily speed, and a flight of Draghkar descended.

ɪɾɝɑldi faʊn hɪmsɛlf faɪɡɹɪŋ fəɹ ɪz laɪf.

Ituralde found himself fighring for his life.

ɝaʊn hɪm, ðə bæɾəlfild wɑz ə tɛɹəbəl mɛs: ɹæŋks dɪstʃɹɔɪd, tʃɹɑləks ɹoʊmɪŋ fɹili fəɹ izi kɪlz, mɹdʒɹɑl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɪp əm ɪndə ətækɪŋ ðə fju ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ paɪk fɔɹmeɪʃənz ɪnstɛd.

Around him, the battlefield was a terrible mess: ranks destroyed, Trollocs roaming freely for easy kills, Myrddraal trying to whip them into attacking the few remaining pike formations instead.

faɪɝz flu ɪn ði ɛɹ əz ði æʃəmən eɪm fəɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks, bʌt ðɛɹ faɪɝz wɝ smɔlɝ, wikɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪn deɪz əɡoʊ. mɛn skɹimd, wɛpənz klæŋd, ən bists ɹɔɹɾ ɪn ðə smoʊk bɪniθ ə skaɪ ʌv tu-blæk klaʊdz.

Fires flew in the air as the Asha'man aimed for the Trollocs, but their fires were smaller, weaker than they had been days ago. Men screamed, weapons clanged, and beasts roared in the smoke beneath a sky of too-black clouds.

ɪɾɝɑldi wɑz bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd. hɪz ɡɑɹdz hæd fɔlən. ət list i hæd sin steɪvən ən ɹɛt daɪ. wʌɾ ə ði ʌðɝz? hi dɪdn si ðɛm. soʊ mɛni daɪɪŋ. soʊ mɛni. ðəɹ wɑz swɛɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz.

Ituralde was breathing hard. His guards had fallen. At least he had seen Staven and Rett die. What of the others? He didn't see them. So many dying. So many. There was sweat in his eyes.

laɪt, hi θɔt. ət list wi ɡeɪv əm ə faɪt. hɛld aʊt lɔŋɡɝ ðən aɪ θɔt pɑsəbəl.

Light, he thought. At least we gave them a fight. Held out longer than I thought possible.

ðəɹ wɝ kɑləmz ə smoʊk tə ðə nɔɹθ. wɛl, wʌn θɪŋ hæd ɡɔn wɛl - ðəɾ æʃəmən taɪməθ hæd dʌn ɪz dʒɑb. ðə sɛkən sɛɾ ə sidʒ ɪkwɪpmənt wɑz bɝnɪŋ. səm ə hɪz ɔfəsɝz hæd kɔld ɪt mædnəs tə sɛn əweɪ wʌn ə hɪz æʃəmən, bʌt wʌn mɔɹ tʃænlɝ wʊdn əv mæɾɝd ɪn ðɪs dɪzæstɝ. ən wən ðə tʃɹɑləks ətæk mɛɹədɑn, ðə læk ə ðoʊz kæɾəpəlts wəd meɪk ə bɪɡ dɪfɝəns.

There were columns of smoke to the north. Well, one thing had gone well - that Asha'man Tymoth had done his job. The second set of siege equipment was burning. Some of his officers had called it madness to send away one of his Asha'man, but one more channeler wouldn't have mattered in this disaster. And when the Trollocs attacked Maradon, the lack of those catapults would make a big difference.

dɔnwiv fɛl. eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk dʒævələn ðət hæd bɪn mɛn fəɹ ɪɾɝɑldi hæd fɔlən loʊ. ðə hɔɹs skɹimd wɪð ðə wɛpən lɑdʒd ɪn ɪts nɛk, blʌd pʌlsɪŋ daʊn ɪts swɛt-fɹʌθ skɪn. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd lɔs maʊns bi-fɔɹ, ən i nu tə ɹoʊl tə ðə saɪd, bʌt wɑz tu ɔf-bæləns ðɪs taɪm. hi hɝɾ ɪz lɛɡ snæp əz i hɪt.

Dawnweave fell. A Trolloc javelin that had been meant for Ituralde had fallen low. The horse screamed with the weapon lodged in its neck, blood pulsing down its sweat-frothed skin. Ituralde had lost mounts be-fore, and he knew to roll to the side, but was too off-balance this time. He heard his leg snap as he hit.

hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, dɪtɝmənd nɑt tə daɪ ɑn ɪz bæk, ən fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɪndə ə sɪɾɪŋ pəzɪʃən. hi dʒɹɑpt ɪz sɔɹd - hɛɹən-mɑɹk ðoʊ ɪt wɑz - ən lɪftəɾ ʌp ə bɹoʊkən, dɪskɑɹɾɪd paɪk ɪn ə fluəd moʊʃən ən ɹæmd ɪt θɹu ðə tʃɛst ʌv ən əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ tʃɹɑlɑk. dɑɹk, stɪŋkɪŋ blʌd koʊɾəd ðə ʃæft, spɝɾɪŋ daʊn ɑntu ɪɾɝɑldiz hænz əz ðə tʃɹɑlɑk skɹimd ən daɪd.

He gritted his teeth, determined not to die on his back, and forced himself up into a sitting position. He dropped his sword - heron-mark though it was - and lifted up a broken, discarded pike in a fluid motion and rammed it through the chest of an approaching Trolloc. Dark, stinking blood coated the shaft, spurting down onto Ituralde's hands as the Trolloc screamed and died.

ðəɹ wɑz θʌndɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ. ðət wɑzn ɑd - ðəɹ wɑz ɔfən θʌndɝ fɹəm ðoʊz klaʊdz, ɔfən ɪɹəli dɪsdʒɔɪntɪd fɹəm ðə bɝsts ə laɪtnɪŋ.

There was thunder in the air. That wasn't odd - there was often thunder from those clouds, often eerily disjointed from the bursts of lightning.

ɪɾɝɑldi hivd, pʊʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tə ðə saɪd baɪ lɛvɝɪŋ ðə paɪk. ðən ə mɹdʒɹɑl sɔ hɪm.

Ituralde heaved, pushing the Trolloc to the side by levering the pike. Then a Myrddraal saw him.

ɪɾɝɑldi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ, bʌt nu hi hæd dʒʌst sin ɪz kɪlɝ. wʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz kəd fɛl ə dʌzən mɛn. feɪsɪŋ ɪt wɪð ə bɹoʊkən lɛɡ . . .

Ituralde reached for his sword, gritting his teeth, but knew he had just seen his killer. One of those things could fell a dozen men. Facing it with a broken leg . . .

hi tʃɹaɪd tə stʌmbəl tə hɪz fiɾ ɛniweɪ. hi feɪld, fɔlɪŋ bækwɝd kɝsɪŋ. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz sɔɹd, pɹipɛɹd tə daɪ əz ðə θɪŋ slʌŋk fɔɹwɝd, muvməns laɪk lɪkwəd.

He tried to stumble to his feet anyway. He failed, falling backward cursing. He raised his sword, prepared to die as the thing slunk forward, movements like liquid.

ə dʌzən æɹoʊz slæmd ɪndə ðə feɪd.

A dozen arrows slammed into the Fade.

ɪɾɝɑldi blɪŋkt əz ðə kɹitʃɝ stʌmbəld. ðə θʌndɝ wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ laʊɾɝ. ɪɾɝɑldi pɹɑp hɪmsɛlf ʌp, ən wɑz əmeɪz tə si θaʊzənz ʌv ʌnfəmɪljɝ hɔɹsmən tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ɪn fɔɹmeɪʃən θɹu ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹæŋks, swipɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝz bɪfɔɹ ðɛm.

Ituralde blinked as the creature stumbled. The thunder was getting louder. Ituralde propped himself up, and was amazed to see thousands of unfamiliar horsemen charging in formation through the Trolloc ranks, sweeping the creatures before them.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn! hi keɪm!

The Dragon Reborn! He came!

bʌt noʊ. ðiz mɛn flu ðə sɑldəiən flæɡ. hi lʊk bæk. ðə ɡeɪts ə mɛɹədɑn wɝ oʊpən, ən ɪɾɝɑldiz taɪɝd sɝvaɪvɝz wɝ biɪŋ əlaʊd tə lɪmp ɪnsaɪd. faɪɝ wɑz flaɪɪŋ fɹəm ðə bæɾəlmənts -  hɪz æʃəmən hæd bɪn əlaʊɾ ʌp tɑp tə ɡɛɾ ə væntədʒ ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild.

But no. These men flew the Saldaean flag. He looked back. The gates of Maradon were open, and Ituralde's tired survivors were being allowed to limp inside. Fire was flying from the battlements -  his Asha'man had been allowed up top to get a vantage on the battlefield.

ə fɔɹs ə twɛnti hɔɹsmən bɹoʊk ɔf ən ɹæn daʊn ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, tʃɹæmplɪŋ ɪt. ðə læs mæn ɪn ðə ɡɹup lɛp fɹi ʌv ɪz sæɾəl ən hækt ət ðə kɹitʃɝ wɪð ə hæn æks. ɔl əkɹɔs ðə bæɾəlfild, ðə tʃɹoʊl-lɑks wɝ ɹʌn daʊn, ʃɑɾ əɹ lænst.

A force of twenty horsemen broke off and ran down the Myrddraal, trampling it. The last man in the group leaped free of his saddle and hacked at the creature with a hand axe. All across the battlefield, the Trol-locs were run down, shot or lanced.

ɪt wʊdn læst. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ɪɾɝɑldiz fɔɹmɝ fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz ən ləpɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp. bʌt ðə sɑldəiən ɹɪlif wəd bi ɪnʌf, wɪð ðoʊz ɡeɪts oʊpən, ən wɪð ði æʃəmən blæstɪŋ ɹikɪŋ dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. ðə ɹɛmnəns ʌv ɪɾɝɑldiz fɔɹs wɝ fliɪŋ tə seɪfti. hi wɑz pɹaʊd tə si bæɹɛɾəl ən kənəl - ðə læst ə hɪz ɡɑɹd -  stʌmbəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə fil təwɔɹɾ ɪm ɑn fʊt, ðɛɹ maʊns noʊ daʊt dɛd, ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz blʌɾid.

It wouldn't last. More and more Trollocs were rolling through Ituralde's former fortifications and loping down the slope. But the Saldaean relief would be enough, with those gates open, and with the Asha'man blasting wreaking destruction. The remnants of Ituralde's force were fleeing to safety. He was proud to see Barettal and Connel - the last of his guard -  stumbling across the field toward him on foot, their mounts no doubt dead, their uniforms bloodied.

hi slɪɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪndə ɪts skæbɝɾ ən pʊl ðə dʒævələn fɹəm dɔn-wivz nɛk. səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ɪt, hi mænədʒ tə stænd. ə ɹaɪɾɝ fɹəm ðə sɑldəiən fɔɹs tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp tə hɪm, ə mæn wɪð ə lin feɪs, ə hʊk noʊz, ən ə sɛɾ ə bʊʃi blæk aɪbɹaʊz. hi wɔɹ ə ʃɔɹt, tʃɹɪm bɪɹd, ən i ɹeɪzd ə blʌɾid sɔɹd tə ɪɾɝɑldi. "ju lɪv."

He slid his sword into its scabbard and pulled the javelin from Dawn-weave's neck. Supporting himself on it, he managed to stand. A rider from the Saldaean force trotted up to him, a man with a lean face, a hooked nose, and a set of bushy black eyebrows. He wore a short, trimmed beard, and he raised a bloodied sword to Ituralde. "You live."

"aɪ du," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛɾ əz ɪz tu ɡɑɹdz ɝaɪvd. "ju kəmæn ðɪs fɔɹs?"

"I do," Ituralde said as his two guards arrived. "You command this force?"

"fɔɹ naʊ," ðə mæn sɛd. "aɪ æm joʊli. kən jə ɹaɪd?"

"For now," the man said. "I am Yoeli. Can you ride?"

"bɛɾɝ ðət ðən steɪɪŋ hɪɹ."

"Better that than staying here."

joʊli ɹitʃt aʊɾ ə hæn ən pʊld ɪɾɝɑldi ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl bɪhaɪn ɪm ɪɾɝɑldiz lɛɡ pɹətɛstəd wɪð ə flɛɹ ə peɪn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn taɪm tə weɪt fəɹ ə stʃɹɛtʃɝ.

Yoeli reached out a hand and pulled Ituralde into his saddle behind him Ituralde's leg protested with a flare of pain, but there wasn't time to wait for a stretcher.

tu ʌðɝ hɔɹsmən tʊk ɪɾɝɑldiz ɡɑɹdz ɑntu ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən sun ðeɪ θɹi wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə sɪɾi əɾ ə ɡæləp.

Two other horsemen took Ituralde's guards onto their horses, and soon they three were riding for the city at a gallop.

"blɛs ju," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ɪt tʊk jə lɔŋ ɪnʌf, ðoʊ."

"Bless you," Ituralde said. "It took you long enough, though."

"aɪ noʊ." joʊliz vɔɪs saʊndəɾ ɑdli ɡɹɪm. "aɪ hoʊp jə ɑɹ wɝθ ðɪs, ɪnveɪɾɝ, fəɹ maɪ ækʃənz ðɪs deɪ wɪl laɪkli kɑs maɪ laɪf."

"I know." Yoeli's voice sounded oddly grim. "I hope you are worth this, invader, for my actions this day will likely cost my life."

"wʌt?"

"What?"

ðə mæn dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ. hi sɪmpli bɔɹ ɪɾɝɑldi ɑn θʌndɝɪŋ hʊvz ɪndə ðə seɪfti ʌv ðə sɪɾi -  sətʃ əz ðət seɪfti wɑz, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə sɪɾi wɑz naʊ bɪsidʒ baɪ ə fɔɹs ə sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd ʃæɾoʊzpɔn.

The man didn't reply. He simply bore Ituralde on thundering hooves into the safety of the city -  such as that safety was, considering the city was now besieged by a force of several hundred thousand Shadowspawn.

mɔɹɡeɪs wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp. noʊbɑdi stɑp hɝ, ðoʊ səm dɪd ɡɪv əɹ ɑd lʊks. ʃi pæs ðə wʊɾɪd nɔɹðɝn ɹɪm. ðə tʃɹiz wɝ bɝloʊk, speɪst əpɑɹt tə əlaʊ fəɹ ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪt, spɹɛɾɪŋ ɑɹmz. ʃi muv bɪniθ ðə baʊz, bɹiðɪŋ dipli ʌv ðə hjuməɾ ɛɹ.

Morgase walked out of the camp. Nobody stopped her, though some did give her odd looks. She passed the wooded northern rim. The trees were burloak, spaced apart to allow for their great, spreading arms. She moved beneath the boughs, breathing deeply of the humid air.

ɡeɪbɹəl hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

Gaebril had been one of the Forsaken.

ʃi ɪvɛntʃəwəli faʊn ə pleɪs wɛɹ ə taɪni haɪlən stʃɹim fɪld ə klf bɪtwin tu ɹɑks ən kɹieɪɾəd ə stɪl, klɪɹ pul. ðə tɔl ɹɑks ɝaʊn ɪt klʌstɝd laɪk ən eɪntʃənt, bɹoʊkən θɹoʊn bɪl fəɹ ə dʒaɪən fɪftin spænz tɔl.

She eventually found a place where a tiny highland stream filled a cleft between two rocks and created a still, clear pool. The tall rocks around it clustered like an ancient, broken throne built for a giant fifteen spans tall.

ðə tʃɹiz bɔɹ livz əbʌv, ðoʊ mɛni lʊk sɪkli. ə θɪnɝ pætʃ ə klaʊdz blu pæst, əlaʊɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz ə sʌnlaɪt tə ɹitʃ daʊn fɹəm ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ. ðət splɪntɝd laɪt ʃoʊn ɪn ɹeɪz θɹu ðə klɪɹ wɔɾɝ, meɪkɪŋ pætʃəz ə laɪɾ ɑn ðə pulz bɑɾəm. mɪnoʊz dɑɹɾɪd bɪtwin ðə pætʃəz, əz ɪf ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾɪŋ ðə laɪt.

The trees bore leaves above, though many looked sickly. A thinner patch of clouds blew past, allowing fingers of sunlight to reach down from the overcast sky. That splintered light shone in rays through the clear water, making patches of light on the pool's bottom. Minnows darted between the patches, as if investigating the light.

mɔɹɡeɪs ɹaʊndəd ðə pul, ðən sɛɾəld ətɑp ə flæt boʊldɝ. ðə saʊnz ə ðə kæmp kəd bi hɝɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. kɔlɪŋ, poʊsts biɪŋ dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kɑɹts ɹætlɪŋ ɑn pæθweɪz.

Morgase rounded the pool, then settled atop a flat boulder. The sounds of the camp could be heard in the distance. Calling, posts being driven into the ground, carts rattling on pathways.

ʃi stɛɹɾ ɪndə ðə pul. wɑz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ heɪtfəl ðən biɪŋ meɪd ðə pɔn ʌv ənʌðɝ? ʌv biɪŋ fɔɹs tə dæns əpɑn ðɛɹ stʃɹɪŋz laɪk ə wʊɾən pʌpət? ɪn əɹ juθ, ʃid ɡɹoʊn wɛl əkweɪntəd wɪð boʊɪŋ bɛɹɔɹ ðə wɪmz ʌv ʌðɝz. ðət hæd bɪn ði oʊnli weɪ fəɹ əɹ tə steɪbəlaɪz əɹ ɹul.

She stared into the pool. Was there anything more hateful than being made the pawn of another? Of being forced to dance upon their strings like a wooden puppet? In her youth, she'd grown well acquainted with bowing berore the whims of others. That had been the only way for her to stabilize her rule.

tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl hæd tʃɹaɪd tə mənɪpjəleɪt hɝ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hid bɪn səksɛsfəl mʌtʃ ə ðə taɪm. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ʌðɝz, tu. soʊ mɛni hu hæd pʊʃt əɹ ðɪs weɪ əɹ ðæt. ʃid spɛn tɛn jɪɹz pændɝɪŋ tə wɪtʃɛvɝ fækʃən wɑz ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst. tɛn jɪɹz sloʊli bɪldɪŋ əlaɪənsəz. ɪt hæd wɝkt. ʃiɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɪn eɪbəl tə mənuvɝ ɑn əɹ oʊn. wən tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl hæd daɪd hʌntɪŋ, mɛni hæd wɪspɝd ðəɾ ɪz pæsɪŋ ɹilis hɝ, bʌt ðoʊz kloʊs tə hɝ hæd noʊn ðət ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn ə lɔŋ weɪ təwɔɹɾ ənsiɾɪŋ ɪz əθɔɹəɾi.

Taringail had tried to manipulate her. In truth, he'd been successful much of the time. There had been others, too. So many who had pushed her this way or that. She'd spent ten years pandering to whichever faction was the strongest. Ten years slowly building alliances. It had worked. She'd eventually been able to maneuver on her own. When Taringail had died hunting, many had whispered that his passing released her, but those close to her had known that she had already gone a long way toward unseating his authority.

ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə vɛɹi deɪ wən ʃid kæst ɔf ðə læst ə ðoʊz u hæd pɹəzum tə bi ðə ɹil paʊɝ bɪhaɪn ðə θɹoʊn. ðət wɑz ðə deɪ ðæt, ɪn əɹ hɑɹt, ʃid tʃɹuli bɪkʌm kwin. ʃid swɔɹn ðət ʃid nɛvɝ lɛɾ ənʌðɝ mənɪpjəleɪɾ əɹ əɡɛn.

She could remember the very day when she'd cast off the last of those who had presumed to be the real power behind the throne. That was the day that, in her heart, she'd truly become Queen. She'd sworn that she'd never let another manipulate her again.

ən ðɛn, jɪɹz leɪɾɝ, ɡeɪbɹəl hæɾ ɝaɪvd. æftɝ ðæt, vɑldə, hu hæd bɪn wɝs. ət list wɪð ɡeɪbɹəl, ʃi hædn ɹilaɪzd wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ðət hæd nʌm ðə wunz.

And then, years later, Gaebril had arrived. After that, Valda, who had been worse. At least with Gaebril, she hadn't realized what was happening. That had numbed the wounds.

fʊtstɛps ɑn fɔlən twɪɡz ənaʊnst ə vɪzəɾɝ. ðə laɪt fɹəm əbʌv dɪmd, ðə θɪnɝ klaʊdz muvɪŋ ɑn. ðə ʃæfs ə laɪt feɪɾəd, ən ðə mɪnoʊz skæɾɝd.

Footsteps on fallen twigs announced a visitor. The light from above dimmed, the thinner clouds moving on. The shafts of light faded, and the minnows scattered.

ðə fʊtstɛps stɑp bɪsaɪɾ əɹ stoʊn. "aɪm livɪŋ," tɑlænvɝz vɔɪs sɛd. "eɪbɑɹə hæz ɡɪvən liv fəɹ ɪz æʃəmən tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz, stɑɹɾɪŋ wɪð səm ə ðə dɪstən sɪɾiz. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɛɹ.

The footsteps stopped beside her stone. "I'm leaving," Tallanvor's voice said. "Aybara has given leave for his Asha'man to make gateways, starting with some of the distant cities. I'm going to Tear.

ɹumɝz seɪ ðɛɹz ə kɪŋ ðəɹ əɡɛn. hiz ɡæðɝɪŋ ən ɑɹmi tə faɪɾ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl. aɪ wɑnə bi wɪð ɪt."

Rumors say there's a king there again. He's gathering an army to fight in the Last Battle. I want to be with it."

mɔɹɡeɪs lʊkt ʌp, stɛɹɪŋ əhɛd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. ɪt wɑzn ɹɪli ə fɔɹəst. "ðeɪ seɪ jə wɝ əz sɪŋɡəl-maɪndəɾ əz ɡoʊldeɪniz," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "ðæt jə wəd nɑt ɹɛst, ðət jə bɛɹli tʊk taɪm tə it, ðət jə spɛn ɛvɹi moʊmən sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə weɪ tə fɹi mi."

Morgase looked up, staring ahead through the trees. It wasn't really a forest. "They say you were as single-minded as Goldeneyes," she said softly. "That you would not rest, that you barely took time to eat, that you spent every moment searching for a way to free me."

tɑlænvɝ sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Tallanvor said nothing.

"aɪv nɛvɝ hæɾ ə mæn də ðət fəɹ mi," ʃi kəntɪnjud. But none of them made me their entire life, their heart. I think Thorn and Gareth loved me, but as something to be held and cared for, then released. I didn't think you'd ever let go."

But this thing I feel for him - this thing that blends my desire and my hatred like two locks in a braid - it is not love."

ʃi tɝn ən lʊk daʊn ət tɑlænvɝ. "aɪ noʊ lʌv, tɑlænvɝ, ən ɡeɪbɹəl nɛvɝ hæɾ ɪt fɹəm mi. aɪ daʊt ðəɾ ə kɹitʃɝ laɪk ɪm kəd kɑmpɹihɛn lʌv."

"aɪ nid taɪm tə θɪŋk. wəd jə ɹɪfɹeɪn, fəɹ naʊ, fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɛɹ?"

hi baʊd. "mɔɹɡeɪs, ɪf jə wɑn ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm mi - ɛniθɪŋ - ɔl jə ɛvɝ nid tə də ɪz æsk. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ meɪd ðət klɪɹ. əl ɹimuv maɪ neɪm fɹəm ðə lɪst."

tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu


CHAPTER 22

ði ɛn ʌv ə lɛdʒənd


The End of a Legend

ət naɪt, ɡɔɪn kʊdn si ðə waɪt taʊɝz wunz. ɪn dɑɹknəs, wʌn kʊdn tɛl ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ə bjuɾəfli ɪntʃɹəkət mjʊɹəl ən ə wɔl fʊl ə mɪsmætʃt taɪlz. ət naɪt, ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl ə tɑɹ vəlɑnz bɪldɪŋz bɪkeɪm ənʌðɝ dɑɹk lʌmp.

At night, Gawyn couldn't see the White Tower's wounds. In darkness, one couldn't tell the difference between a beautifully intricate mural and a wall full of mismatched tiles. At night, the most beautiful of Tar Valon's buildings became another dark lump.

ən ət naɪt, ðə hoʊlz ən skɑɹz ɑn ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɝ pætʃt wɪð ə bændɪdʒ ə dɑɹknəs.

And at night, the holes and scars on the White Tower were patched with a bandage of darkness.

ʌv kɔɹs, ɑn ə naɪɾ əz dɑɹk əz ðiz klaʊdz kɑzd, wʌn ɔlsoʊ kʊdn tɛl ðə taʊɝz kʌlɝ. waɪɾ əɹ blæk; ət naɪt, ɪt dɪdn ɹɪli mæɾɝ.

Of course, on a night as dark as these clouds caused, one also couldn't tell the Tower's color. White or black; at night, it didn't really matter.

ɡɔɪn wɔk ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz, wɛɹɪŋ stɪf tʃɹaʊzɝz ən koʊɾ ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. laɪk ə junəfɔɹm, bʌɾ ə noʊ spəsɪfɪk əlidʒəns. hi dɪdn sim tə hæv ə spəsɪfɪk əlidʒəns ðiz deɪz.

Gawyn walked the White Tower grounds, wearing stiff trousers and coat of red and gold. Like a uniform, but of no specific allegiance. He didn't seem to have a specific allegiance these days.

ɔlmoʊst ʌnkɑnʃəsli, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ði istɝn taʊɝ ɛntʃɹəns əz ɪf tə klaɪm ʌp tə ɛɡwinz slipɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝz. hi sɛɾ ɪz dʒɔ, tɝnɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ.

Almost unconsciously, he found himself walking toward the eastern tower entrance as if to climb up to Egwene's sleeping chambers. He set his jaw, turning the other way.

hi ʃʊɾə bɪn slipɪŋ. bʌɾ æftɝ nɪɹli ə wik ʌv ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz dɔɹ ət naɪt, hi wɑz  - əz soʊlʒɝz laɪk tə seɪ - ɑn ə mɪdnaɪt lʌntʃ. pɝhæps i cʊɾə steɪɾ ɪn ɪz ɹumz tə ɹɪlæks, bʌɾ ɪz kɔɹɾɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝz bæɹəks fɛl kənfaɪnɪŋ.

He should have been sleeping. But after nearly a week of guarding Egwene's door at night, he was  - as soldiers liked to say - on a midnight lunch. Perhaps he could have stayed in his rooms to relax, but his quarters in the White Tower's barracks felt confining.

nɪɹbaɪ, tu smɔl fɛɹəl kæts stɔk θɹu tʌfs ʌv ɡɹæs, aɪz ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə tɔɹtʃlaɪɾ ʌv ə ɡɑɹd poʊst. ðə kæts hʌŋkɝd loʊ, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm əz ɪf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ - fəɹ ə bɹif moʊmənt - wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt hid bi wɝθ ətæk-ɪŋ. ən ənsin aʊl kɹuzd ɪn ði ɛɹ əbʌv, ði oʊnli ɛvəɾəns ʌv ɪts pæs-ɪŋ ə sɑlətɛɹi fɛðɝ ðət floʊɾəd daʊn. ɪt wɑz iziɝ tə pɹitɛn ət naɪt.

Nearby, two small feral cats stalked through tufts of grass, eyes reflecting the torchlight of a guard post. The cats hunkered low, watching him as if considering - for a brief moment - whether or not he'd be worth attack-ing. An unseen owl cruised in the air above, the only evidence of its pass-ing a solitary feather that floated down. It was easier to pretend at night.

səm mɛn lɪv ðɛɹ ɪntaɪɝ lɪvz ðət weɪ, pɹɪfɝɪŋ ðə kɝɾənz ə dɑɹk-nɛs tə ði oʊpən wɪndoʊz ə deɪlaɪt, kəz ðeɪ lɛɾ əm si ðə wɝld ɔl ɪn ʃædoʊ.

Some men lived their entire lives that way, preferring the curtains of dark-ness to the open windows of daylight, because they let them see the world all in shadow.

ɪt wɑz sʌmɝ naʊ, bʌt ðoʊ ðə deɪ hæd bɪn hɑt, ðə naɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒli koʊld. hi ʃɪvɝɾ əɾ ə pæsɪŋ bɹiz. ðəɹ hædn bɪn ɛni mɝɾɝz sɪns ðə dɛθ ə ðəɾ ənfɔɹtʃənət waɪt. wən wəd ðə kɪlɝ stʃɹaɪk əɡɛn? hi - əɹ ʃi - kəd bi muvɪŋ θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz ət ðɪs moʊmənt, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə sɑlətɛɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ðoʊz kæts sɝtʃt fəɹ maɪs ɛɡwin hæd sɛn ɪm əweɪ fɹəm əɹ dɔɹ, bʌt ðət dɪdn min i kʊdn bi ɑn ðə wɑtʃ. wʌt ɡʊd wɑz ɪt tə wɔk ðə ɡɹaʊnz? hi ʃəd bi ɪndɔɹz, wɛɹ i hæɾ ə tʃæns ə duɪŋ səm ɡʊd. ɡɔɪn meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə wʌn ə ðə sɝvən ɛntʃɹənsəz.

It was summer now, but though the day had been hot, the night was strangely cold. He shivered at a passing breeze. There hadn't been any murders since the death of that unfortunate White. When would the killer strike again? He - or she - could be moving through the hallways at this moment, searching for a solitary Aes Sedai as those cats searched for mice Egwene had sent him away from her door, but that didn't mean he couldn't be on the watch. What good was it to walk the grounds? He should be indoors, where he had a chance of doing some good. Gawyn made his way to one of the servant entrances.

ðə loʊ-silɪŋɡd hɔlweɪ ɪnsaɪd wɑz klin ən wɛl lɪt, laɪk ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊɝ, ðoʊ ðə flɔɹ wɑz sɛt wɪð dʌl ɡɹeɪ sleɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡleɪz taɪlz. ən oʊpən ɹum tə hɪz ɹaɪt ɹisaʊndɪd wɪð læftɝ ən tʃæɾɪŋ, ɔf-duɾi ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ taɪm wɪð ðɛɹ kɑmɹædz. ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv əm bɛɹli ə ɡlæns, bʌt ðən fɹoʊz.

The low-ceilinged hallway inside was clean and well lit, like the rest of the Tower, though the floor was set with dull gray slate instead of glazed tiles. An open room to his right resounded with laughter and chatting, off-duty guardsmen enjoying time with their comrades. Gawyn gave them barely a glance, but then froze.

hi lʊk bæk ɪn, ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ səm ə ðə mɛn. "mɑzoʊni? sɛlɑɹk? zæŋ? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə mɛn əbaʊt?"

He looked back in, recognizing some of the men. "Mazone? Celark? Zang? What are you men about?"

ðə θɹi lʊkt ʌp wɪð əlɑɹm, ðən ʃəɡɹɪn. ðeɪ wɝ əmʌŋ əbaʊɾ ə dʌzən jʌŋɡəlɪŋz u wɝ dɪsɪŋ ən smoʊkɪŋ paɪps wɪð ði ɔf-duɾi taʊɝ ɡɑɹdzmɪn. ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz stʌmbəl tə ðɛɹ fiɾ ən ɡeɪv səluts, ðoʊ hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðɛɹ kəmændɝ. ðeɪ dɪdn sim tə ɹilaɪz ðæt.

The three looked up with alarm, then chagrin. They were among about a dozen Younglings who were dicing and smoking pipes with the off-duty Tower guardsmen. The Younglings stumbled to their feet and gave salutes, though he was no longer their commander. They didn't seem to realize that.

sɛlɑɹk, fɔɹmoʊst əmʌŋ ðɛm, heɪsən oʊvɝ tə ɡɔɪn. hi wɑz ə lin fɛloʊ wɪð laɪt bɹaʊn hɛɹ ən θɪk fɪŋɡɝz. "maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd. "nʌθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, maɪ lɔɹd. dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl hɑɹmləs fʌn."

Celark, foremost among them, hastened over to Gawyn. He was a lean fellow with light brown hair and thick fingers. "My Lord," he said. "Nothing important, my Lord. Just a little harmless fun."

"ðə wɔɹɾɝz doʊn laɪk ðɪs kaɪndə bɪheɪvjɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ju noʊ ðæt, sɛlɑɹk. ɪf ɪt ɡɛts ɝaʊn ðət jəɹ steɪɪŋ ʌp ðɪs leɪt dɪsɪŋ, jəl nɛvɝ kənvɪns ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə teɪk ju."

"The Warders don't like this kind of behavior," Gawyn said. "You know that, Celark. If it gets around that you're staying up this late dicing, you'll never convince an Aes Sedai to take you."

sɛlɑɹk ɡɹɪməst. "jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd."

Celark grimaced. "Yes, my Lord."

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɪlʌktən ɪn ðət ɡɹɪmɑs. "wʌt?" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aʊt wɪð ɪt, mæn."

There was something reluctant in that grimace. "What?" Gawyn said. "Out with it, man."

"wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd," sɛlɑɹk sɛd. "ɪts ðət səm ʌv ʌs, wi ɑɹən soʊ ʃʊɹ ðət wi wɑnə bi wɔɹɾɝz.

"Well, my Lord," Celark said. "It's that some of us, we aren't so sure that we want to be Warders.

nɑɾ ɔl ʌv əs keɪm hɪɹ fəɹ ðæt, jə noʊ. səm wɝ laɪk ju, wɑntɪŋ tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð ðə bɛst. ən ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs . .  wɛl, θɪŋz əv tʃeɪnʒd naʊ."

Not all of us came here for that, you know. Some were like you, wanting to train with the best. And the rest of us . .  well, things have changed now."

"wʌt θɪŋz?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"What things?" Gawyn asked.

"fulɪʃ θɪŋz, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə mæn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn. "jɔɹ ɹaɪt, ʌv kɔɹs. ðɛɹz ɝli spɑɹɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ. bʌt, wɛl, wiv sin wɔɹ. wɝ soʊlʒɝz naʊ. biɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ, ɪts ɔl ə mæn ʃəɾ əspaɪɹ tə. bʌt səm ʌv ʌs, wid ɹæðɝ nɑt si wʌt wɪv naʊ ɛnd. jə noʊ?" ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli. "wɛn aɪ fɝs keɪm tə ðə taʊɝ,"

"Foolish things, my Lord," the man said, looking down. "You're right, of course. There's early sparring tomorrow. But, well, we've seen war. We're soldiers now. Being a Warder, it's all a man should aspire to. But some of us, we'd rather not see what we have now end. You know?" Gawyn nodded slowly. "When I first came to the Tower,"

sɛlɑɹk sɛd, "aɪ wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tə bi ə wɔɹɾɝ. naʊ aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ aɪ wɑnə spɛn maɪ laɪf pɹətɛkt-ɪŋ wʌn wʊmən, sɑlətɛɹi, ɹoʊvɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd."

Celark said, "I wanted nothing more than to be a Warder. Now I don't know that I want to spend my life protect-ing one woman, solitary, roving about the countryside."

"ju kəd bi wɔɹɾɝ tə ə bɹaʊn əɹ waɪt," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "æn steɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ."

"You could be Warder to a Brown or White," Gawyn said. "And stay in the Tower."

sɛlɑɹk fɹaʊnd. "wɪð ɔl ɹɪspɛkt, maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ θɪŋk ðət maɪt bi dʒʌst əz bæd. wɔɹɾɝz . . . ðeɪ doʊn laɪv laɪk ʌðɝ mɛn."

Celark frowned. "With all respect, my Lord, I think that might be just as bad. Warders . . . they don't live like other men."

"ðæts fəɹ sɝɾən," ɡɔɪn sɛd, aɪz lɪftɪŋ ʌpwɝd, təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwinz dɪstən kɔɹɾɝz. hi wəd nɑt ɡoʊ sikɪŋ ðət dɔɹ. hi fɔɹst ɪz ɡeɪz bæk daʊn tə sɛlɑɹk. "ðɛɹz noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn tʃuzɪŋ ə dɪfɹən pæθ."

"That's for certain," Gawyn said, eyes lifting upward, toward Egwene's distant quarters. He would not go seeking that door. He forced his gaze back down to Celark. "There's no shame in choosing a different path."

"ði ʌðɝz meɪk ɪt saʊn laɪk ðəɹ ɪz."

"The others make it sound like there is."

"ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ ɹɔŋ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ɡæðɝ ðoʊz ə jə hu wɑnə ɹɪmeɪn wɪð ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz ən ɹipɔɹt tə kæptən tʃʌbn təmɑɹoʊ. əl spik wɪð hɪm. əl weɪdʒɝ i kəd juz jə əz ə dɪvɪʒən ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd. hi lɔst ə lɑɾ ə mɛn ɪn ðə sintʃæn ətæk."

"The others are wrong," Gawyn said. "Gather those of you who want to remain with the Younglings and report to Captain Chubain tomorrow. I'll speak with him. I'll wager he could use you as a division in the Tower Guard. He lost a lot of men in the Seanchan attack."

sɛlɑɹk ɹɪlæks vɪzəbli. "jud də ðæt, maɪ lɔɹd?"

Celark relaxed visibly. "You'd do that, my Lord?"

"ʌv kɔɹs. ɪt wɑz ən ɑnɝ tə lid jə mɛn."

"Of course. It was an honor to lead you men."

"du jə θɪŋk . . . meɪbi jə kəd dʒɔɪn wɪð ʌs?" ðə juθs vɔɪs wɑz hoʊpfəl.

"Do you think . . . maybe you could join with us?" The youth's voice was hopeful.

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪv ənʌðɝ pæθ tə teɪk. bʌt, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, əl ɛn ʌp kloʊs ɪnʌf tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ju." hi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə ɹum. "ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ ɡeɪmz. əl spik tə mækzim fəɹ jə əz wɛl." mækzim wɑz ðə stɝn, θɪk-ɑɹmd wɔɹɾɝ kɝənli liɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ sɛʃənz.

Gawyn shook his head. "I've another path to take. But, the Light willing, I'll end up close enough to keep an eye on you." He nodded toward the room. "Go back to your games. I'll speak to Makzim for you as well." Makzim was the stern, thick-armed Warder currently leading the training sessions.

sɛlɑɹk nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪtfəli, hɝiɪŋ bæk tə ði ʌðɝz. ɡɔɪn kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, wɪʃɪŋ ɪz tʃɔɪsəz wɝ əz izi əz ðoʊz ə hɪz mɛn.

Celark nodded gratefully, hurrying back to the others. Gawyn continued down the corridor, wishing his choices were as easy as those of his men.

lɔst ɪn θɔt, hid klaɪm hæfweɪ tə ɛɡwinz ɹumz bɪfɔɹ i stɑp tə ɹilaɪz wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. / nid sʌmθɪŋ tə dɪstʃɹæk mi. ði aʊɝ wɑzn tu leɪt. pɝhæps i kəd faɪn bɹaɪn ən tʃæt.

Lost in thought, he'd climbed halfway to Egwene's rooms before he stopped to realize what he was doing. / need something to distract me. The hour wasn't too late. Perhaps he could find Bryne and chat.

ɡɔɪn meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə bɹaɪnz ɹumz. ɪf ɡɔɪn hæɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pəzɪʃən əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɹaɪnz wɑz nɪɹli əz ɑd: wɔɹɾɝ tə ðə fɔɹmɝ æmɪɝlɪn, dʒɛnɝəl ʌv ɛɡwinz kɑŋkɝɪŋ ɑɹmi, ən ɹɪnaʊnd ɡɹeɪt kæptən. bɹaɪnz dɔɹ wɑz oʊpən ə kɹæk, ɪmɪɾɪŋ ə laɪn ə laɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə blu-taɪl kɔɹəɾɝ. ðət wɑz ɪz hæbət wən i wɑz ɪn ən əweɪk, ʃəd wʌn ə hɪz ɔfəsɝz nid hɪm. mɛni naɪts bɹaɪn wɑz əweɪ, steɪɪŋ ət wʌn ə hɪz kəmæn sɛntɝz ɝaʊn ði aɪlən əɹ ɪn ə nɪɹbaɪ vɪlədʒ.

Gawyn made his way to Bryne's rooms. If Gawyn had a strange position among the Aes Sedai, Bryne's was nearly as odd: Warder to the former Amyrlin, general of Egwene's conquering army, and renowned great captain. Bryne's door was open a crack, emitting a line of light across the blue-tiled corridor. That was his habit when he was in and awake, should one of his officers need him. Many nights Bryne was away, staying at one of his command centers around the island or in a nearby village.

ɡɔɪn nɑk sɔfli.

Gawyn knocked softly.

"kʌm." bɹaɪnz vɔɪs wɑz fɝm ən fəmɪljɝ. ɡɔɪn slɪpt ɪn, ðən ɹɪtɝn ðə dɔɹ tə ɪts kɹæk pəzɪʃən. bɹaɪn sæɾ əɾ ə ɹɪkəɾi-lʊkɪŋ dɛsk, wɝkɪŋ ɑn ə lɛɾɝ. hi ɡlænst ət ɡɔɪn. "dʒʌst ə moʊmənt."

"Come." Bryne's voice was firm and familiar. Gawyn slipped in, then returned the door to its cracked position. Bryne sat at a rickety-looking desk, working on a letter. He glanced at Gawyn. "Just a moment."

ɡɔɪn weɪɾəd. ðə wɔlz wɝ peɪpɝd wɪð mæps ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ændɝ, kɛɹhin ən sɝaʊndɪŋ ɹidʒənz. mɛni bɔɹ ɹisənt noʊteɪʃənz ɪn ɹɛd tʃɑk. bɹaɪn wɑz pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ wɔɹ. ðə noʊteɪʃənz meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ i fɛl hiɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli hæv tə dɪfɛn tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪtsɛlf əɡɛns tʃɹɑləks.

Gawyn waited. The walls were papered with maps of Tar Valon, Andor, Cairhien and surrounding regions. Many bore recent notations in red chalk. Bryne was preparing for war. The notations made it clear he felt he'd eventually have to defend Tar Valon itself against Trollocs.

sɛvɹəl mæps ʃoʊd vɪlədʒəz əkɹɔs ðə nɔɹðɝn pɑɹɾ ə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd, lɪstɪŋ ðɛɹ fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz -  ɪf ɛni - ən ðɛɹ lɔɪəlti tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðeɪd bi juz fəɹ səplaɪ dʌmps ən fɔɹwɝd pəzɪʃənz.

Several maps showed villages across the northern part of the countryside, listing their fortifications -  if any - and their loyalty to Tar Valon. They'd be used for supply dumps and forward positions.

ənʌðɝ mæp hæd sɝkəlz pɔɪntɪŋ aʊɾ eɪntʃənt wɑtʃtaʊɝz, fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz ən ɹuənz.

Another map had circles pointing out ancient watchtowers, fortifications and ruins.

ðəɹ wɑz ə məθɑɾəkəl ɪnɛvɪɾəbɪlɪti tə bɹaɪnz kælkjəleɪʃənz, ən ə sɛns ə ɝdʒənsi. hi wɑzn lʊkɪŋ tə bɪl fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz, bʌt tə juz ðoʊz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn pleɪs. hi wɑz muvɪŋ tʃɹups ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒəz i fɛl moʊs jusfəl; ənʌðɝ mæp ʃoʊd pɹɑɡɹɛs ɪn æktɪv ɹəkɹutmənt.

There was a methodical inevitability to Bryne's calculations, and a sense of urgency. He wasn't looking to build fortifications, but to use those already in place. He was moving troops into the villages he felt most useful; another map showed progress in active recruitment.

ɪt wɑzn əntɪl ɡɔɪn stʊd ðəɹ - smɛlɪŋ ðə mʌsti sɛn ʌv oʊl peɪpɝ ən bɝnɪŋ kændəlz -  ðəɾ i fɛl ðə ɹiæləɾi ʌv ði ɪmpɛndɪŋ wɔɹ. ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ sun. ðə dʒɹæɡən wəd bɹeɪk ðə silz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. ðə pleɪs i hæd toʊld ɛɡwin tə mit hɪm, ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ, wɑz mɑɹkt ɪn bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə mæps. ɪt wɑz nɔɹθ, ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə ʃaɪnɝ.

It wasn't until Gawyn stood there - smelling the musty scent of old paper and burning candles -  that he felt the reality of the impending war. It was coming soon. The Dragon would break the seals of the Dark One's prison. The place he had told Egwene to meet him, the Field of Merrilor, was marked in bright red on the maps. It was north, on the border of Shienar.

ðə dɑɹk wʌn. lus əpɑn ðə wɝld. laɪt! ɪt meɪd ɡɔɪnz oʊn pɹɑbləmz ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkənt.

The Dark One. Loose upon the world. Light! It made Gawyn's own problems insignificant.

bɹaɪn fɪnɪʃt ɪz lɛɾɝ, sændɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ, foʊldɪŋ ɪt, ən ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz wæks ən sil. "ɪts ə lɪɾəl leɪt fəɹ kɔlɪŋ ɑn pipəl, sʌn."

Bryne finished his letter, sanding the paper, folding it, and reaching for his wax and seal. "It's a little late for calling on people, son."

"aɪ noʊ, bʌɾ aɪ θɔt jə maɪt bi ʌp."

"I know, but I thought you might be up."

"æn soʊ aɪ æm." bɹaɪn dʒɹɪbəld wæks ɑntu ðə lɛɾɝ. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə nid?"

"And so I am." Bryne dribbled wax onto the letter. "What is it you need?"

"ædvaɪs," ɡɔɪn sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə stul.

"Advice," Gawyn said, sitting on a stool.

"ənlɛs ɪts əbaʊt ðə bɛst weɪ tə kɔɹɾɝ ə ɡɹup ə mɛn əɹ haʊ tə fɔɹɾɪfaɪ ə hɪltɑp, jəl faɪn maɪ ædvaɪs lækɪŋ. bʌt wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə wɑnə tɔk əbaʊt?"

"Unless it's about the best way to quarter a group of men or how to fortify a hilltop, you'll find my advice lacking. But what is it you want to talk about?"

"ɛɡwin fɝbeɪd mi tə pɹətɛk hɝ."

"Egwene forbade me to protect her."

"aɪm sɝɾən ði æmɪɝlɪn hæɾ əɹ ɹizənz," bɹaɪn sɛd, kɑmli silɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ.

"I'm certain the Amyrlin had her reasons," Bryne said, calmly sealing the letter.

"fulɪʃ wʌnz," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ʃi hæz noʊ wɔɹɾɝ, ən ðəɹ ɪz ə kɪlɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ." wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, hi θɔt.

"Foolish ones," Gawyn said. "She has no Warder, and there is a killer in the Tower." One of the Forsaken, he thought.

"boʊθ tʃɹu," bɹaɪn sɛd. "bʌt wʌt dʌz ðəɾ əv tə də wɪð ju?"

"Both true," Bryne said. "But what does that have to do with you?"

"ʃi nidz maɪ pɹətɛkʃən."

"She needs my protection."

"dɪd ʃi æsk fəɹ jəɹ pɹətɛkʃən?"

"Did she ask for your protection?"

"noʊ"

"No"

"ɪndid. əz aɪ ɹikɔl, ʃi dɪdn æsk jə tə kʌm wɪð əɹ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ iðɝ nɔɹ dɪd ʃi æsk fəɹ jə tə bɪɡɪn fɑloʊɪŋ əɹ əbaʊt laɪk ə haʊn ðəɾ əz lɔst ɪz mæstɝ."

"Indeed. As I recall, she didn't ask you to come with her into the Tower either nor did she ask for you to begin following her about like a hound that has lost his master."

"bʌt ʃi nidz mi!" ɡɔɪn sɛd.

"But she needs me!" Gawyn said.

"ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. ðə læs taɪm jə θɔt ðæt, jə - wɪð maɪ hɛlp -  ʌpsɛt wiks' wɝθ ə hɝ wɝk tə ɹiunaɪt ðə waɪt taʊɝ. səmtaɪmz, sʌn, əɹ hɛlp ɪz nɑt niɾəd. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɹili ɔfɝd, əɹ haʊ ɝdʒən ðət hɛlp meɪ sim."

"Interesting. The last time you thought that, you - with my help -  upset weeks' worth of her work to reunite the White Tower. Sometimes, son, our help is not needed. No matter how freely offered, or how urgent that help may seem."

ɡɔɪn foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz, əneɪbəl tə lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl, lɛst i dɪstɝb ə mæp ʃoʊɪŋ ɔɹtʃɝdz əkɹɔs ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹisaɪd. wʌn vɪlədʒ nɪɹ dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt wɑz sɝkəl fɔɹ taɪmz, fəɹ səm ɹizən. "soʊ jəɹ ædvaɪs ɪz tə lɛɾ əɹ ɹɪmeɪn ɪkspoʊzd, pɝhæps tə teɪk ə naɪf ɪn ðə bæk."

Gawyn folded his arms, unable to lean against the wall, lest he disturb a map showing orchards across the surrounding countryside. One village near Dragonmount was circled four times, for some reason. "So your advice is to let her remain exposed, perhaps to take a knife in the back."

"aɪ hævənt ɡɪvən ɛni ædvaɪs," bɹaɪn sɛd, lifɪŋ θɹu səm ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ɪz dɛsk, hɪz fɝm feɪs lɪt baɪ flɪkɝɪŋ kændəllaɪt. "aɪ hæv oʊnli meɪɾ ɑbzɝveɪʃənz, ðoʊ aɪ θɪŋk ɪt kjʊɹiəs ðət jə kənklud ðət jə ʃəd liv əɹ əloʊn."

"I haven't given any advice," Bryne said, leafing through some reports on his desk, his firm face lit by flickering candlelight. "I have only made observations, though I think it curious that you conclude that you should leave her alone."

"aɪ . . . bɹaɪn, ʃi dʌzn meɪk sɛnsəl"

"I . . . Bryne, she doesn't make sensel"

ðə kɔɹnɝ ə bɹaɪnz maʊθ ɹeɪzd ɪn ə ɹaɪ smaɪl. hi loʊɝɾ ɪz peɪpɝz, tɝnɪŋ tə ɡɔɪn. "aɪ wɔɹn jə ðət maɪ ædvaɪs wəd bi ʌv lɪɾəl jus. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ ænsɝz ðət wɪl sut ju.

The corner of Bryne's mouth raised in a wry smile. He lowered his papers, turning to Gawyn. "I warned you that my advice would be of little use. I'm not sure if there are answers that will suit you.

bʌt lemi æsk ðɪs: wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə wɑnt, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd?"

But let me ask this: What is it you want, Gawyn Trakand?"

"ɛɡwin," hi sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "aɪ wɑnə bi hɝ wɔɹɾɝ."

"Egwene," he said immediately. "I want to be her Warder."

"wɛl, wɪtʃ ɪz ɪt?"

"Well, which is it?"

ɡɔɪn fɹaʊnd.

Gawyn frowned.

"du jə wɑn ɛɡwin, əɹ dʒju wɑnə bi hɝ wɔɹɾɝ?"

"Do you want Egwene, or do you want to be her Warder?"

"tə bi hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ən . . . ænd, wɛl, tə mɛɹi hɝ. aɪ lʌv hɝ, bɹaɪn."

"To be her Warder, of course. And . . . and, well, to marry her. I love her, Bryne."

"ɪt simz tə mi ðət ðoʊz ɑɹ tu dɪfɹən θɪŋz. sɪməlɝ, bʌt sɛpɹət. bʌt, ʌðɝ ðən θɪŋz tə də wɪð ɛɡwin, wʌɾ ɪz ɪt ðət jə wɑnt?"

"It seems to me that those are two different things. Similar, but separate. But, other than things to do with Egwene, what is it that you want?"

nʌθɪŋ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ʃiz ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Nothing," Gawyn said. "She's everything."

"wɛl, ðɛɹz jəɹ pɹɑbləm."

"Well, there's your problem."

"haʊ ɪz ðəɾ ə pɹɑbləm? aɪ lʌv hɝ."

"How is that a problem? I love her."

soʊ jə sɛd." bɹaɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɡɔɪn, wʌn ɑɹm ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ði ʌðɝ ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz lɛɡ. ɡɔɪn ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɝdʒ tə skwɝm bɪniθ ðət ɡeɪz. "ju ɔlweɪz wɝ ðə pæʃənət wʌn, ɡɔɪn. laɪk jəɹ mʌðɝ ən jəɹ sɪstɝ. ɪmpʌlsɪv, nɛvɝ kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ laɪk jəɹ bɹʌðɝ."

So you said." Bryne regarded Gawyn, one arm on the table, the other resting on his leg. Gawyn resisted the urge to squirm beneath that gaze. "You always were the passionate one, Gawyn. Like your mother and your sister. Impulsive, never calculating like your brother."

ɡɑləd dʌzn kælkjəleɪt," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "hi dʒʌst æks."

Galad doesn't calculate," Gawyn said. "He just acts."

noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "pɝhæps aɪ spoʊk ɹɔŋ - ɡɑləd meɪ nɑt bi kælkju-lɑɾɪŋ, bʌɾ i ɪzən ɪmpʌlsɪv.

No," Bryne said. "Perhaps I spoke wrong - Galad may not be calcu-lating, but he isn't impulsive.

tə bi ɪmpʌlsɪv ɪz tə ækt wɪθaʊt kɛɹfəl θɔt; ɡɑləɾ əz ɡɪvən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə θɔt. hiz wɝkt aʊɾ ɪz koʊɾ ə mɝæləɾi ðət weɪ. hi kən ækt kwɪkli ən dɪsaɪsɪvli bi-kɑz hiz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪtɝmənd wʌt tə du.

To be impulsive is to act without careful thought; Galad has given everything a great deal of thought. He's worked out his code of morality that way. He can act quickly and decisively be-cause he's already determined what to do.

"ju ækt wɪð pæʃən. jə doʊn ækt kəz ə ðə weɪ jə θɪŋk, bʌt kəz ə ðə weɪ jə fil. ɪn ə ɹʌʃ, wɪð ə snæp ʌv ɪmoʊʃən. ðət ɡɪvz jə stʃɹɛŋkθ. jə kən ækt wən jə nid tə, ðən sɔɹt θɹu ðə ɹæməfəkeɪʃənz leɪɾɝ. jəɹ ɪnstɪŋks ɑɹ juʒəwəli ɡʊd, dʒʌs laɪk jəɹ mʌðɝz wɝ. bʌt kəz ə ðæt, juv nɛvɝ hæd tə feɪs wʌt tə də wən jəɹ ɪnstɪŋks lɛd jə ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ dɝɛkʃən."

"You act with passion. You don't act because of the way you think, but because of the way you feel. In a rush, with a snap of emotion. That gives you strength. You can act when you need to, then sort through the ramifications later. Your instincts are usually good, just like your mother's were. But because of that, you've never had to face what to do when your instincts lead you in the wrong direction."

ɡɔɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf nɑɾɪŋ.

Gawyn found himself nodding.

"bʌt sʌn," bɹaɪn sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. "ə mæn ɪz mɔɹ ðən wʌn dʒɹaɪv wʌn ɡoʊl. noʊ wʊmən wɑns ðəɾ ɪn ə mæn. ɪt simz tə mi ðət mɛn u spɛn taɪm meɪkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ə ðɛmsɛlvz - ɹæðɝ ðən pɹəfɛsɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪvoʊʃən - ɑɹ ðə wʌnz u ɡɛt sʌmwɛɹ. boʊθ wɪð wɪmən, ən wɪð laɪf ɪtsɛlf." bɹaɪn ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn. "soʊ, ɪf aɪ hæv ædvaɪs fəɹ ju, ɪts ðɪs: faɪn aʊɾ u jə wəd bi wɪθaʊɾ ɛɡwin, ən ðən fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə fɪɾ əɹ ɪndə ðæt. aɪ θɪŋk ðæts wʌɾ ə wʊmən - "

"But son," Bryne said, leaning forward. "A man is more than one drive one goal. No woman wants that in a man. It seems to me that men who spend time making something of themselves - rather than professing their devotion - are the ones who get somewhere. Both with women, and with life itself." Bryne rubbed his chin. "So, if I have advice for you, it's this: Find out who you would be without Egwene, and then figure out how to fit her into that. I think that's what a woman - "

"jɔɹ ən ɛkspɝɾ ɑn wɪmən naʊ?" ə nu vɔɪs æskt.

"You're an expert on women now?" a new voice asked.

ɡɔɪn tɝnd, sɝpɹaɪzd, tə faɪn sɪuən sɑntʃ pʊʃɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

Gawyn turned, surprised, to find Siuan Sanche pushing open the door.

bɹaɪn dɪdn mɪs ə bit. "juv bɪn ðəɹ lɪsnɪŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf, sɪuən, tə noʊ ðæts nɑt wʌt ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɑz əbaʊt."

Bryne didn't miss a beat. "You've been there listening long enough, Siuan, to know that's not what the conversation was about."

sɪuən snɔɹɾɪd, bʌsəlɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum wɪð ə pɑɾ ə ti. "ju ʃəd bi ɪn bɛd," ʃi sɛd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɡɔɪn æftɝ ə kɝsɝi ɡlæns.

Siuan snorted, bustling into the room with a pot of tea. "You should be in bed," she said, ignoring Gawyn after a cursory glance.

"vɛɹi tʃɹu," bɹaɪn sɛd kæʒəwəli. "ɑdli, ðə nidz ə ðə læn doʊn səbmɪt tə maɪ wɪmz."

"Very true," Bryne said casually. "Oddly, the needs of the land don't submit to my whims."

"mæps kən bi stʌɾid ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

"Maps can be studied in the morning."

"æn ðeɪ kən bi stʌɾid ət naɪt. ən dʊɹɪŋ ði æftɝnun. ɛvɹi aʊɝ aɪ spɛn kəd min liɡz ʌv ɡɹaʊn dɪfɛndəɾ ɪf tʃɹɑləks bɹeɪk θɹu."

"And they can be studied at night. And during the afternoon. Every hour I spend could mean leagues of ground defended if Trollocs break through."

sɪuən saɪd laʊdli, hændɪŋ ɪm ə kʌp, ðən pɔɹɪŋ ðə ti, wɪtʃ smɛld ə klaʊdbɛɹi. ɪt wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ɑd tə si sɪuən - hu, kəz ə hɝ stɪlɪŋ, lʊk laɪk ə wʊmən ɡɔɪnz eɪdʒ -  mʌðɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹɪzəl dʒɛnɝəl bɹaɪn.

Siuan sighed loudly, handing him a cup, then pouring the tea, which smelled of cloudberry. It was decidedly odd to see Siuan - who, because of her stilling, looked like a woman Gawyn's age -  mothering the grizzled General Bryne.

sɪuən tɝn tə ɡɔɪn əz bɹaɪn æksɛptɪɾ ɪz dʒɹɪŋk. "æn ju, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd," ʃi sɛd. "aɪv bɪn minɪŋ tə spik tə ju. ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn, tɛlɪŋ əɹ wʌt ʃi ʃəd du? ɑnəsli.

Siuan turned to Gawyn as Bryne accepted his drink. "And you, Gawyn Trakand," she said. "I've been meaning to speak to you. Giving orders to the Amyrlin, telling her what she should do? Honestly.

mɛn sim tə θɪŋk ðət wɪmən ɑɹ nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ðɛɹ pɝsənəl mɛsənʒɝz, səmtaɪmz. jə dʒɹim ʌp ɔl sɔɹts ə ɹɪdɪkjələs skimz, ðən ɪkspɛkt əs tə sʌmhaʊ kæɹi ðɛm aʊt."

Men seem to think that women are nothing more than their personal messengers, sometimes. You dream up all sorts of ridiculous schemes, then expect us to somehow carry them out."

ʃi aɪd hɪm, nɑt lʊkɪŋ laɪk ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛni ɹɪspɑns ʌðɝ ðən ən əʃeɪm loʊɝɪŋ ə ði aɪz. ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv ðəɾ ən ðən meɪɾ ə heɪsti ɛɡzɪt tə əvɔɪd fɝðɝ bʊliɪŋ.

She eyed him, not looking like she expected any response other than an ashamed lowering of the eyes. Gawyn gave that and then made a hasty exit to avoid further bullying.

hi wɑzn sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ɛniθɪŋ bɹaɪn hæd sɛd. ðə mæn wɑz nɑθ- ɪŋ ɪf nɑt kənsɪstənt, ən i hæd ɹɪpiɾɪd ðə seɪm θimz tə ɡɔɪn bi- fɔɹ. θɪŋk ɪnstɛɾ ə biɪŋ ɪmpʌlsɪv; bi dɪlɪbɝeɪt. bʌt hid spɛnt wiks θɪŋkɪŋ, hɪz aɪdiəz tʃeɪsɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn sɝkəlz laɪk flaɪz tʃɹæpt ɪn ə dʒɑɹ.

He wasn't surprised by anything Bryne had said. The man was noth- ing if not consistent, and he had repeated the same themes to Gawyn be- fore. Think instead of being impulsive; be deliberate. But he'd spent weeks thinking, his ideas chasing one another in circles like flies trapped in a jar.

hid ɡɑɾən noʊwɛɹ.

He'd gotten nowhere.

ɡɔɪn wɔk ðə hɔlweɪz, noʊɾɪŋ tʃʌbnz ɡɑɹdz poʊstɪɾ ət ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪntɝvəlz. hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf i wɑzn klaɪmɪŋ tə ɛɡwin; hi wɑz mɪɹli tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɑɹdz. ən jɛt, hi sun faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə hɔlweɪ nɪɹ ði æmɪɝlɪnz kɔɹɾɝz. dʒʌst wʌn hɔlweɪ oʊvɝ. hid tʃɛk ɑn əɹ kwɪkli ən . . .

Gawyn walked the hallways, noting Chubain's guards posted at regular intervals. He told himself he wasn't climbing to Egwene; he was merely checking on the guards. And yet, he soon found himself in a hallway near the Amyrlin's quarters. Just one hallway over. He'd check on her quickly and . . .

ɡɔɪn fɹoʊz. wʌɾ æm aɪ duɪŋ? hi θɔt.

Gawyn froze. What am I doing? he thought.

ə lɑɾ ə hɪz nɝvəsnəs tənaɪt keɪm fɹəm nɑt noʊɪŋ ɪf ɛɡwin wɑz pɹɑpɝli ɡɑɹɾəd əɹ nɑt.

A lot of his nervousness tonight came from not knowing if Egwene was properly guarded or not.

hi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə slip əntɪl -  noʊ, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf fɔɹsfəli. ðɪs taɪm, əl də əz ʃi æsks. hi tɝn tə ɡoʊ.

He wouldn't be able to sleep until -  No, he told himself forcefully. This time, I'll do as she asks. He turned to go.

ə saʊn meɪɾ ɪm hɛzəteɪt, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. fʊtfɔlz ən kloʊðɪŋ ɹʌslɪŋ. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt fəɹ nɑvəsɪz, bʌt sɝvəns maɪt wɛl bi dɪlɪvɝɪŋ leɪt milz. bɹaɪn ən ɡɔɪn wɝn ði oʊnli wʌnz u kɛpt ənjuʒəwəl aʊɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

A sound made him hesitate, glancing over his shoulder. Footfalls and clothing rustling. It was too late for novices, but servants might well be delivering late meals. Bryne and Gawyn weren't the only ones who kept unusual hours in the White Tower.

ɪt keɪm əɡɛn. soʊ sɑft, bɛɹli ɑɾəbəl. fɹaʊnɪŋ, ɡɔɪn slɪpt ɔf ɪz buts, ðən snik fɔɹwɝd tə ɡlæns ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ.
