It came again. So soft, barely audible. Frowning, Gawyn slipped off his boots, then sneaked forward to glance around the corner.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ. ɛɡwinz dɔɹ - ɪnleɪd wɪð ɡoʊld ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə - sæt kloʊzd, ðə hɔlweɪ ɛmpti. saɪɪŋ, ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, linɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl tə slɪp ɪz buts bæk ɑn. hi wɪʃt ɛɡwin wəɾ ət lis lɛt tʃʌbn sɛt ɡɑɹdz əɾ əɹ ɹum. livɪŋ ɪɾ ʌn-wɑtʃt wɑz  -  sʌmθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ dʒʌs daʊn fɹəm ɛɡwinz dɔɹweɪ. ɡɔɪn fɹoʊz. ðəɹ wɑzn mʌtʃ ʌv ə dɑɹk pætʃ ðɛɹ, oʊnli ə ʃædoʊ ə fju ɪntʃəz waɪd meɪd baɪ ən ælkoʊv, bʌɾ əz i stʌɾid ðət pætʃ, hi hæd tʃɹʌbəl kipɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɑn ɪt. hɪz ɡeɪz slɪd fɹi, laɪk ə dɑləp ə bʌɾɝ ɑn ə hɑt tɝnəp.

There was nothing. Egwene's door - inlaid with gold in the shape of Avendesora - sat closed, the hallway empty. Sighing, Gawyn shook his head, leaning back against the wall to slip his boots back on. He wished Egwene would at least let Chubain set guards at her room. Leaving it un-watched was  -  Something moved in the shadow just down from Egwene's doorway. Gawyn froze. There wasn't much of a dark patch there, only a shadow a few inches wide made by an alcove, But as he studied that patch, he had trouble keeping his eyes on it. His gaze slid free, like a dollop of butter on a hot turnip.

ɪt simd ... ɪt sim ðət ðə dɑɹknəs wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən i hæɾ ɝɪdʒənəli θɔt. waɪ kʊdn i lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ ɪt?

It seemed ... it seemed that the darkness was larger than he had originally thought. Why couldn't he look straight at it?

ðəɹ wɑz ə flæʃ ə muvmənt, ən sʌmθɪŋ spʌn ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɡɔɪn θɹu hɪmsɛlf tə ðə saɪd, ən stil stʃɹʌk stoʊn. wʌn buɾ ɑn, hi dʒɹɑp ði ʌðɝ əz i pʊld ɪz sɔɹd fɹi. ðə naɪf ðət hæd bɪn θɹoʊn fəɹ ɪz hɑɹt skɪɾəd əkɹɔs ðə taɪl flɔɹ.

There was a flash of movement, and something spun in the air. Gawyn threw himself to the side, and steel struck stone. One boot on, he dropped the other as he pulled his sword free. The knife that had been thrown for his heart skidded across the tiled floor.

ɡɔɪn pɪɹd ɹaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ, tɛns. sʌmwʌn wɑz fliɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. sʌmwʌn wɛɹɪŋ ɔl blæk, ə hʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə hɛd.

Gawyn peered round the corner, tense. Someone was fleeing down the hallway. Someone wearing all black, a hood over the head.

ɡɔɪn tʊk ɔf æftɝ ðə pɝsən, sɔɹd hɛl bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ɑɹmz pʌmp-ɪŋ, ɡeɪɾ ɑkwɝɾ əz ɪz ənbuɾɪd fʊt hɪɾ ɑpəzəɾ ɪz buɾɪd wʌn. ði əsæsən wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli fæst. ɡɔɪn bɛloʊd ði əlɑɹm, hɪz vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə saɪlən hɔlz ə ðə taʊɝ; ðən i kʌt lɛft. ði əsæsən wəɾ əv tə tɝn ən kʌm ʌp ðə hɔlweɪ hɪɹ tə ðə ɹaɪt.

Gawyn took off after the person, sword held before him, arms pump-ing, gait awkward as his unbooted foot hit opposite his booted one. The assassin was extremely fast. Gawyn bellowed the alarm, his voice echoing through the silent halls of the Tower; then he cut left. The assassin would have to turn and come up the hallway here to the right.

ɡɔɪn bɝst ɪndə ənʌðɝ hɔlweɪ, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ɑn ə hɛɾɪŋ ðət wəd kʌɾ ɔf ði əsæsən. hi skɪɾəd ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ.

Gawyn burst into another hallway, charging on a heading that would cut off the assassin. He skidded around the corner.

ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz ɛmpti. hæd ði əsæsən dʌbəl bæk? ɡɔɪn kɝst əz i ɹæn fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɹitʃt ði ɝɪdʒənəl hɔlweɪ ət ði ʌðɝ ɛnd. ɪt wɑz ɛmpti. ə dɔɹweɪ, pɝhæps? ɔl wəd bi dɛɾ ɛnz. ɪf ɡɔɪn weɪɾəd əntɪl hɛlp keɪm . . .

The hallway was empty. Had the assassin doubled back? Gawyn cursed as he ran forward and reached the original hallway at the other end. It was empty. A doorway, perhaps? All would be dead ends. If Gawyn waited until help came . . .

noʊ, ɡɔɪn θɔt, spɪnɪŋ. dɑɹknəs. lʊk fəɹ dɑɹknəs. ðəɹ wɑz ə dip pætʃ ʌv ɪt baɪ ə dɔɹfɹeɪm tə hɪz lɛft. fɑɹ tu smɔl tə hoʊld ɛniwʌn, bʌɾ i hæd ðət seɪm sɛns ə dɪsɔɹiənteɪʃən əz i lʊkt əɾ ɪt.

No, Gawyn thought, spinning. Darkness. Look for darkness. There was a deep patch of it by a doorframe to his left. Far too small to hold anyone, but he had that same sense of disorientation as he looked at it.

ə pɝsən lɛpt aʊt, swɪŋɪŋ ə sɔɹd fəɹ ɡɔɪnz hɛd. hi wɪpt ɪz bleɪɾ ɪndə kʌɾɪŋ ðə ɹidz, nɑkɪŋ əsaɪd ði ətæk. ði əsæsən wɑz mʌtʃ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɡɔɪn, soʊ hi ʃʊɾə hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ ædvæntɪdʒ ɪn ɹitʃ. jɛt ði əsæsən muvd wɪð ə blɝɪŋ spid, sɔɹd dɑɹɾɪŋ ət ɡɔɪn ɪn ə sɪɹiz ə θɹʌsts, nɑt juzɪŋ ɛni sɔɹd fɔɹmz ɡɔɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd.

A person leaped out, swinging a sword for Gawyn's head. He whipped his blade into Cutting the Reeds, knocking aside the attack. The assassin was much shorter than Gawyn, so he should have had a strong advantage in reach. Yet the assassin moved with a blurring speed, sword darting at Gawyn in a series of thrusts, not using any sword forms Gawyn recognized.

ɡɔɪn fɛl ɪndə twɪstɪŋ ðə wɪnd, əz i wɑz fɔɹs tə ækt əz ɪf i wɝ sɝaʊndəd. hi bɛɹli kɛp ði ətækɝ ət beɪ. hi kəd hɪɹ jɛlz ɪn ðə dɪstəns - ɡɑɹdz ɹɪspɑndɪŋ tə hɪz kɔl. hi ʃaʊɾəd əɡɛn.

Gawyn fell into Twisting the Wind, as he was forced to act as if he were surrounded. He barely kept the attacker at bay. He could hear yells in the distance - guards responding to his call. He shouted again.

hi kəd sɛns fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ɪn ði ətækɝz muvz; ði əsæsən hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə dɪfit ɡɔɪn kwɪkli. wɛl, ɡɔɪn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə seɪm, bʌt foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðɪs əpoʊnənt wɑz vɛɹi dɪfəkəlt.

He could sense frustration in the attacker's moves; the assassin had expected to defeat Gawyn quickly. Well, Gawyn had expected the same, but focusing on this opponent was very difficult.

ɡɔɪnz bloʊz - wən i kəd meɪk əm - hɪɾ ɛɹ wən ðeɪ ʃʊɾə lændəɾ ɑn flɛʃ. ɡɔɪn twɪstəd tə ðə saɪd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz bleɪd fəɹ bɔɹ ɹʌʃəz daʊn ðə maʊntən. bʌt ðət ɡeɪv ði əsæsən ən oʊpənɪŋ; hi flʌŋ ənʌðɝ naɪf ət ɡɔɪn, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪm tə ðə saɪd.

Gawyn's blows - when he could make them - hit air when they should have landed on flesh. Gawyn twisted to the side, raising his blade for Boar Rushes Down the Mountain. But that gave the assassin an opening; he flung another knife at Gawyn, forcing him to the side.

ðə naɪf klæŋd əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ən ði əsæsən flɛd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. ɡɔɪn ɹʌʃt æftɝ, bʌɾ i kʊdn kip ʌp. sun ði əsæsən wɑz fɑɹ əweɪ, dɑɹɾɪŋ tə ðə lɛft. ðət dɝɛkʃən lɛd tə ə sɪɹiz ʌv ɪntɝsɛkʃənz.

The knife clanged against the wall, and the assassin fled down the hallway. Gawyn rushed after, but he couldn't keep up. Soon the assassin was far away, darting to the left. That direction led to a series of intersections.

sətʃ spid, ɡɔɪn θɔt, stɑpɪŋ, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ ɪn ɡæsps, hænz ɑn niz. ɪɾ ɪzənt nætʃɹəl. tu ʌv tʃʌbnz ɡɑɹdz ɝaɪvd ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, sɔɹdz ət ðə ɹɛɾi. ɡɔɪn pɔɪntəd.

Such speed, Gawyn thought, stopping, breathing in and out in gasps, hands on knees. It isn't natural. Two of Chubain's guards arrived a moment later, swords at the ready. Gawyn pointed.

"əsæsən. lɪsnɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwinz dɔɹ. wɛn ðət weɪ."

"Assassin. Listening at Egwene's door. Went that way."

wʌn ɹæn wɛɹ i pɔɪntəd. ði ʌðɝ wɛn tə ɹeɪz ðə dʒɛnɝəl əlɑɹm.

One ran where he pointed. The other went to raise the general alarm.

laɪt! ɡɔɪn θɔt. wʌɾ ɪf aɪ dɪdn ɪntɝʌpt ɪm lɪsnɪŋ? wʌɾ ɪf aɪ ɪntɝʌptɪɾ ɪm ɑn ɪz weɪ aʊt?

Light! Gawyn thought. What if I didn't interrupt him listening? What if I interrupted him on his way out?

ɡɔɪn dæʃt tə ɛɡwinz dɔɹ, fətiɡ ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ. sɔɹɾ aʊt, hi tɛstəd ðə dɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ənlɑkt!

Gawyn dashed to Egwene's door, fatigue evaporating. Sword out, he tested the door. It was unlocked!

"ɛɡwin!" hi kɹaɪd, θɹoʊɪŋ ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən lipɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum.

"Egwene!" he cried, throwing the door open and leaping into the room.

ðəɹ wɑz ə sʌɾən ɪksploʊʒən ə laɪɾ ən ə kɹæʃɪŋ saʊnd. ɡɔɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɹæpt ʌp ɪn sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ: ɪnvɪzəbəl kɔɹdz, toʊɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ði ɛɹ. hɪz sɔɹd fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ɪz maʊθ fɪld wɪð ən ənsin fɔɹs.

There was a sudden explosion of light and a crashing sound. Gawyn found himself wrapped up in something strong: invisible cords, towing him into the air. His sword fell to the ground, and his mouth filled with an unseen force.

ən soʊ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i faʊn hɪmsɛlf hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə silɪŋ, dɪsɑɹmd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ, əz ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf wɔk fɹəm əɹ bɛdʒɹum. ʃi wɑz əlɝɾ ən fʊli dʒɹɛst ɪn ə kɹɪmzən dʒɹɛs tʃɹɪmd wɪð ɡoʊld. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk plizd.

And so it was that he found himself hanging from the ceiling, disarmed, struggling, as the Amyrlin herself walked from her bedroom. She was alert and fully dressed in a crimson dress trimmed with gold. She did not look pleased.

mæt sæt bɪsaɪd ði ɪnz hɑɹθ, wɪʃɪŋ ðə faɪɝ wɝ ə lɪɾəl lɛs wɔɹm. hi kəd fil ɪts hit θɹu ðə leɪɝz ə hɪz ɹæɡəd dʒækəɾ ən waɪt ʃɝt, mætʃt baɪ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɝkmənz θɪk tʃɹaʊzɝz.

Mat sat beside the inn's hearth, wishing the fire were a little less warm. He could feel its heat through the layers of his ragged jacket and white shirt, matched by a pair of workman's thick trousers.

ðə buts ɑn ɪz fit hæd ɡʊd soʊlz, bʌt ðə saɪdz wɝ wɔɹn. hi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ɪz hæt, ən ɪz skɑɹf wɑz pʊld ʌp ɝaʊn ðə bɑɾəm hæf ə hɪz feɪs əz i lin bæk ɪn ðə maʊntən oʊk tʃɛɹ.

The boots on his feet had good soles, but the sides were worn. He did not wear his hat, and his scarf was pulled up around the bottom half of his face as he leaned back in the mountain oak chair.

ɪleɪn stɪl hæɾ ɪz mədæljən. hi fɛl neɪkəd wɪθaʊɾ ɪt. hi hæɾ ə ʃɔɹtsɔɝd sɪɾɪŋ baɪ hɪz tʃɛɹ, bʌt ðət wɑz moʊsli fəɹ ʃoʊ. ə wɔkɪŋ stæf lin ɪnəsənli bɪsaɪɾ ɪt; hi wəd ɹæðɝ jus ðæt, əɹ ðə naɪvz hɪɾən ɪn ɪz koʊt. bʌɾ ə sɔɹd wɑz mɔɹ vɪzəbəl, ən wəd meɪk ðə fʊtpædz u sɔntɝd θɹu ðə stʃɹits ə loʊ keɪɛmlɪn θɪŋk twaɪs.

Elayne still had his medallion. He felt naked without it. He had a shortsword sitting by his chair, but that was mostly for show. A walking staff leaned innocently beside it; he would rather use that, or the knives hidden in his coat. But a sword was more visible, and would make the footpads who sauntered through the streets of Low Caemlyn think twice.

"aɪ noʊ waɪ jəɹ æskɪŋ æftɝ hɪm," tʃɛt sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə mæn laɪk tʃɛɾ ɪn nɪɹli ɛvɹi tævɝn. oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv sin mɛn laɪk mæt bi bɔɹn, ɡɹoʊ ʌp, ən daɪ, ən wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk ʌv ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz ɪf jə ɡɑɾ ɪnʌf dʒɹɪŋk ɪn ðɛm. əɹ ɔfən ɪf jə dɪdnt.

"I know why you're asking after him," Chet said. There was a man like Chet in nearly every tavern. Old enough to have seen men like Mat be born, grow up, and die, and willing to talk of all those years if you got enough drink in them. Or often if you didn't.

ðə stʌbəl ɑn tʃɛts lɔŋ feɪs wɑz dæpəl sɪlvɝ, ən i wɔɹ ə lɑpsaɪɾɪd kæp. hɪz pætʃt koʊt hæd wʌns bɪn blæk, ən ðə ɹɛd-ænd-waɪɾ ɪnsɪɡniə ɑn ɪz pɑkət wɑz tu feɪɾəd tə ɹid. ɪt wɑz veɪɡli mɪlətɛɹi, ən wʌn dɪd nɑt juʒəwəli ɡɛt skɑɹz laɪk ðə θɪk, æŋɡɹi wʌn ɑn ɪz tʃik ən nɛk fɹəm ə bɑɹ faɪt.

The stubble on Chet's long face was dappled silver, and he wore a lopsided cap. His patched coat had once been black, and the red-and-white insignia on his pocket was too faded to read. It was vaguely military, and one did not usually get scars like the thick, angry one on his cheek and neck from a bar fight.

"aɪ," tʃɛt kəntɪnjud, "mɛni ɑɹ əskɪn' æftɝ ðə liɾɝ ə ðət bænd.

"Aye," Chet continued, "many are askin' after the leader of that Band.

wɛl, ðɪs mʌɡ ʌv eɪl ɪz əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd, soʊ lemi ɡɪv jə səm ædvaɪs. jə wɔk laɪk jə noʊ wɪtʃ ɛn ə ðət sɔɹd minz bɪznəs, bʌt jud bi ə ful tə tʃælənʒ ðət wʌn. pɹɪns ə ɹeɪvənz, lɔɹɾ ə lʌk. hi feɪst oʊl dɛθ hɪmsɛlf ən daɪs fəɹ ɪz fjutʃɝ, hi dɪd. eɪnt nɛvɝ lɔst ə faɪt."

Well, this mug of ale is appreciated, so let me give you some advice. You walk like you know which end of that sword means business, but you'd be a fool to challenge that one. Prince of Ravens, Lord of Luck. He faced old death himself and diced for his future, he did. Ain't never lost a fight."

mæt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. hi lin bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ. ðɪs wɑz ɪz fɔɹθ tæf-ɝn ðɪs naɪt, ən ɪn θɹi ʌv əm i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn ɹumɝz əbaʊt meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. bɛɹli ə lɪk ə tʃɹuθ tə ðɛm. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz'

Mat said nothing. He leaned back in his chair. This was his fourth tav-ern this night, and in three of them he had been able to find rumors about Matrim Cauthon. Barely a lick of truth to them. Blood and bloody ashes'

oʊ, ʃʊɹ, ðəɹ wɝ teɪlz ʌv ʌðɝ pipəl, tu. moʊst əbaʊt ɹænd, itʃ wʌn meɪkɪŋ ðə kʌlɝz swɝl wən i hɝd ðɛm. tiɹ hæd fɔlən tə ðə sintʃæn, noʊ ɪljən, noʊ ɹænd hæd dɪfiɾəd əm ɔl ən wɑz faɪɾɪŋ ðə læs bæɾəl ɹaɪt naʊ. noʊ! hi vɪzəɾəd wɪmən ɪn ðɛɹ slip, ɡɛɾɪŋ əm wɪð tʃaɪld. noʊ, ðət wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌn. noʊ, mæt wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌn!

Oh, sure, there were tales of other people, too. Most about Rand, each one making the colors swirl when he heard them. Tear had fallen to the Seanchan, no Illian, no Rand had defeated them all and was fighting the Last Battle right now. No! He visited women in their sleep, getting them with child. No, that was the Dark One. No, Mat was the Dark One!

blʌɾi stɔɹiz. ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz liv mæt əloʊn. səm i kəd tʃɹeɪs bæk tə ðə bænd -  laɪk ðə stɔɹi ʌv ə sɪɾi fʊl ə ðə dɛɾ əweɪkənɪŋ bʌt mɛni ʌv ðə pipəl kleɪm ðət ðə stɔɹiz hæd kʌm fɹəm ðɛɹ ʌŋkəl əɹ kʌzən, əɹ nɛfju.

Bloody stories. They were supposed leave Mat alone. Some he could trace back to the Band -  like the story of a city full of the dead awakening But many of the people claimed that the stories had come from their uncle or cousin, or nephew.

mæt flɪk tʃɛɾ ə kɑpɝ. ðə mæn tɪpt ɪz hæt pəlaɪtli ən wɛn tə ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf ənʌðɝ dʒɹɪŋk.

Mat flicked Chet a copper. The man tipped his hat politely and went to get himself another drink.

mæt dɪd nɑt fil laɪk dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. hi hæɾ ə səspɪʃən ðət ðoʊz pɪktʃɝz ə hɪm wɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv waɪ ðə stɔɹiz wɝ spɹɛɾɪŋ soʊ kwɪkli. ɪn ðə læs tævɝn i hæd vɪzəɾəd, sʌmwʌn hæɾ æktʃəli  pʊld aʊɾ ə kɑpi ʌv ðə skɛtʃ - foʊldəɾ ən ɹɪŋkəld - ən ʃoʊn ɪt tə hɪm. noʊbɑdi hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪm soʊ fɑɹ, ðoʊ.

Mat did not feel like drinking. He had a suspicion that those pictures of him were part of why the stories were spreading so quickly. In the last tavern he had visited, someone had actually pulled out a copy of the sketch - folded and wrinkled - and shown it to him. Nobody had recognized him so far, though.

ðə hɑɹθfaɪɝ kəntɪnjud tə kɹækəl. loʊ keɪɛmlɪn wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ, ən ɛntɝpɹaɪzɪŋ mɛn hæd ɹilaɪz ðət pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ ɹumz ən dʒɹɪŋks fəɹ ðə tʃɹænziəns kəd meɪk ə hɛlθi pɹɑfət. soʊ ʃæntiz hæd stɑɹɾəd tə bɪkʌm tævɝnz, ən ðoʊz hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɡɹoʊ ɪndə fʊl ɪnz.

The hearthfire continued to crackle. Low Caemlyn was growing, and enterprising men had realized that providing rooms and drinks for the transients could make a healthy profit. So shanties had started to become taverns, and those had begun to grow into full inns.

wʊd wɑz ɪn haɪ dɪmænd, ən mɛni ʌv ðə mɝsənɛɹi bænz hæd teɪkən tə wʊdkʌɾɪŋ. səm wɝkt ɑnəsli, peɪɪŋ ðə kwinz lɛvi fəɹ kleɪmz. ʌðɝz wɝk lɛs liɡəli. ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn hæŋʒɪŋz fəɹ ɪt. hu wəɾ əv θɔt? mɛn hæŋɪŋ fəɹ poʊtʃɪŋ tʃɹiz? wʌt nɛkst? mɛn hæŋɪŋ fəɹ stilɪŋ dɝt?

Wood was in high demand, and many of the mercenary bands had taken to woodcutting. Some worked honestly, paying the Queen's levy for claims. Others worked less legally. There had already been hangings for it. Who would have thought? Men hanging for poaching trees? What next? Men hanging for stealing dirt?

loʊ keɪɛmlɪn hæd tʃeɪnʒd dʒɹæstɪkli, ɹoʊdz spɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp, bɪldɪŋz biɪŋ ɛnlɑɹdʒd. ə fju jɪɹz, ən loʊ keɪɛmlɪn wəd bi ə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf! ðeɪɾ əv tə bɪld ənʌðɝ wɔl tə kloʊz ɪɾ ɪn.

Low Caemlyn had changed drastically, roads springing up, buildings being enlarged. A few years, and Low Caemlyn would be a city itself! They'd have to build another wall to close it in.

ðə ɹum smɛld ə dɝɾ ən swɛt, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ soʊ ðən ʌðɝ tævɝnz. spɪlz wɝ kwɪkli klin ʌp ən ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz lʊkt iɡɝ tə hæv wɝk. wʌn ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ə kwaɪət smaɪl, ɹifɪlɪŋ ɪz mʌɡ ən ʃoʊɪŋ səm æŋkəl. mæt meɪd ʃʊɹ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɝ; ʃi wəd bi ɡʊd fəɹ tælmɑnz.

The room smelled of dirt and sweat, but no more so than other taverns. Spills were quickly cleaned up and the serving girls looked eager to have work. One in particular gave him a quiet smile, refilling his mug and showing some ankle. Mat made sure to remember her; she would be good for Talmanes.

mæt lɪftəɾ ʌp ɪz skɑɹf ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɪŋk. hi fɛlt laɪk ə ful wɛɹɪŋ ðə skɑɹf ðɪs weɪ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu hɑt fəɹ ə hʊɾɪd kloʊk, ən ðə bɪɹd hæd bɪn tɔɹtʃɝ. ivən wɪð ðə skɑɹf ɑn ɪz feɪs, hi dɪd nɑt stæn aʊt tu mʌtʃ ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn; hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli tʌf wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð ɪz feɪs ɑb-skjʊɹd. hi ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ i hæɾ ə bæd skɑɹ i wɑntəd tə kʌvɝ; ʌðɝz æz-sumd i hæɾ ə baʊnti ɑn ɪz hɛd. boʊθ wɝ æktʃəli  tʃɹu, ənfɔɹtʃənətli.

Mat lifted up his scarf enough to drink. He felt like a fool wearing the scarf this way. But it was too hot for a hooded cloak, and the beard had been torture. Even with the scarf on his face, he did not stand out too much in Low Caemlyn; he was not the only tough walking around with his face ob-scured. He explained that he had a bad scar he wanted to cover; others as-sumed he had a bounty on his head. Both were actually true, unfortunately.

hi sæt fəɹ ə taɪm, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə dænsɪŋ fleɪmz ə ðə hɑɹθ. tʃɛts wɔɹnɪŋ kɑzd ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl pɪt tə oʊpən ɪn mæts stʌmək. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɪz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən ɡɹu, ðə mɔɹ laɪkli hi wəd bi tʃælənʒd. ðəɹ wəd bi ɡɹeɪt noʊɾɝaɪəti ɪn kɪlɪŋ ðə pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz. wɛɹ hæd ðeɪ ɡɑɾən ðət neɪm? blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!

He sat for a time, staring into the dancing flames of the hearth. Chet's warning caused an uncomfortable pit to open in Mat's stomach. The greater his reputation grew, the more likely he would be challenged. There would be great notoriety in killing the Prince of the Ravens. Where had they gotten that name? Blood and bloody ashes!

ə fɪɡjɝ dʒɔɪn ɪm ət ðə faɪɝ. læŋki ən boʊni, noʊl lʊk laɪk ə skɑɹɛkɹoʊ hu hæd dʌstɪd hɪmsɛlf ɔf ən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡoʊ tə taʊn. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz waɪt hɛɹ ən lɛðɝi feɪs, noʊl wɑz əz spɹaɪ əz mɛn hæf ɪz eɪdʒ. wən i wɑz hænlɪŋ ə wɛpən, ɛniweɪ. ʌðɝ taɪmz i simd əz klʌmzi əz ə mjul ɪn ə daɪnɪŋ pɑɹlɝ.

A figure joined him at the fire. Lanky and bony, Noal looked like a scarecrow who had dusted himself off and decided to go to town. Despite his white hair and leathery face, Noal was as spry as men half his age. When he was handling a weapon, anyway. Other times he seemed as clumsy as a mule in a dining parlor.

"jɔɹ kwaɪt ðə noʊɾəbəl mæn," noʊl sɛd tə mæt, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz pɑmz tə ðə faɪɝ. "wɛn jə stʌmbəld əkɹɔs mi ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, aɪ hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ ɪlʌstʃɹiəs kʌmpəni aɪd faɪn maɪsɛlf ɪn. ɡɪv ðɪs ə fju mɔɹ mʌnθs ən jəl bi mɔɹ feɪməs ðən dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ."

"You're quite the notable man," Noal said to Mat, holding out his palms to the fire. "When you stumbled across me in Ebou Dar, I had no idea what illustrious company I'd find myself in. Give this a few more months and you'll be more famous than Jain Farstrider."

mæt hʌŋkɝd daʊn fɑɹðɝ ɪndə hɪz tʃɛɹ.

Mat hunkered down farther into his chair.

"mɛn ɔlweɪz θɪŋk ɪt wəd bi ə ɡɹæn tə bi noʊn ɪn ɛvɹi tævɝn ən ɛvɹi sɪɾi," noʊl sɛd sɔfli. "bʌt bɝn mi ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən dʒʌst ə hɛdeɪk."

"Men always think it would be a grand to be known in every tavern and every city," Noal said softly. "But burn me if it isn't just a headache."

"wʌt dʒju noʊ ʌv ɪt?"

"What do you know of it?"

"dʒaɪn kəmpleɪn əbaʊɾ ɪt," noʊl sɛd sɔfli.

"Jain complained about it," Noal said softly.

mæt ɡɹʌntɪd. θɔɹn ɝaɪv nɛkst. hi wɑz dʒɹɛst əz ə mɝtʃəns sɝvənt, wɛɹɪŋ ə blu aʊtfɪt ðət wɑz nɑt tu faɪn, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ nɑɾ ɪn dɪsɹɪpɛɹ. hi wɑz kleɪmɪŋ tə hæv kʌm tə loʊ keɪɛmlɪn tə dətɝmən wɛðɝ ɪz mæstɝ wəd bi wɛl ædvaɪz tə pʊɾ ə ʃoʊpfɹʌn hɪɹ.

Mat grunted. Thorn arrived next. He was dressed as a merchant's servant, wearing a blue outfit that was not too fine, but also not in disrepair. He was claiming to have come to Low Caemlyn to determine whether his master would be well advised to put a shopfront here.

θɔɹn pʊld ɔf ðə dɪsɡaɪz wɪð əplɑm, wæksɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz tə pɔɪns ən spikɪŋ wɪð ə feɪn mʊɹændiən æksɛnt. mæt hæɾ ɔfɝd tə kʌm ʌp wɪð ə bækstɔɹi fəɹ ɪz ækt, bʌt θɔɹn hæd kɔft ən sɛd ðəɾ i ɔlɹɛɾi hæd wʌn wɝkt aʊt. fleɪmɪŋ laɪɝ ʌv ə ɡlimən.

Thorn pulled off the disguise with aplomb, waxing his mustaches to points and speaking with a faint Murandian accent. Mat had offered to come up with a backstory for his act, but Thorn had coughed and said that he already had one worked out. Flaming liar of a gleeman.

θɔɹn pʊld ʌp ə tʃɛɹ, siɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf dɛləkətli, əz ɪf i wɝ ə sɝvən u θɔt haɪli ʌv hɪmsɛlf. "ɑ, wʌɾ ə weɪst ə maɪ taɪm ðɪs wɑz! maɪ mæstɝ ɪnsɪsts ðəɾ aɪ əsoʊsiət wɪð sətʃ ɹæbəl əz ðɪs! ən hɪɹ aɪ faɪn ðə wɝst ə ðə lɑt."

Thorn pulled up a chair, seating himself delicately, as if he were a servant who thought highly of himself. "Ah, what a waste of my time this was! My master insists that I associate with such rabble as this! And here I find the worst of the lot."

noʊl tʃʌkəl sɔfli.

Noal chuckled softly.

"ɪf oʊnli," θɔɹn sɛd dʒɹəmæɾɪkli, "aɪ hæd bɪn ɪnstɛd sɛn tə ðə kæmp ə ðə mədʒɛstɪk, əmeɪzɪŋ, ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl, feɪməs meɪtʃɹim kɔθən! ðən aɪ wəd sɝɾənli hæv - "

"If only," Thorn said dramatically, "I had been instead sent to the camp of the majestic, amazing, indestructible, famous Matrim Cauthon! Then I would certainly have - "

bɝn mi, θɔɹn," mæt sɛd. "lɛɾ ə mæn sʌfɝ ɪn pis."

Burn me, Thorn," Mat said. "Let a man suffer in peace."

θɔɹn læft, weɪvɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl ən baɪɪŋ dʒɹɪŋks fəɹ ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. hi ɡeɪv əɹ ən ɛkstʃɹə kɔɪn ən kwaɪətli æskt əɹ tə kip kɑ-swəl ɪɹz fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ tu kloʊs tə ðə hɑɹθ.

Thorn laughed, waving over the serving girl and buying drinks for the three of them. He gave her an extra coin and quietly asked her to keep ca-sual ears from getting too close to the hearth.

'ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə wɑnə mit hɪɹ?" noʊl æskt.

'Are you sure you want to meet here?" Noal asked.

"ɪɾəl du," mæt sɛd. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi sin bæk ɪn kæmp, lɛs ðə ɡoʊləm lʊk ðəɹ fəɹ hɪm.

"It'll do," Mat said. He did not want to be seen back in camp, lest the gholam look there for him.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," noʊl sɛd. "wi noʊ wɛɹ ðə taʊɝ ɪz, ən kən ɡɛt ðɛɹ, əsumɪŋ mæt pɹoʊkjʊɹz əs ə ɡeɪtweɪ."

"All right, then," Noal said. "We know where the tower is, and can get there, assuming Mat procures us a gateway."

"aɪ wɪl," mæt sɛd.

"I will," Mat said.

"aɪ hævən bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn ɛniwʌn u hæz ɡɔn ɪnsaɪd," noʊl kəntɪnjud "sʌm seɪ ɪts hɔntəd," θɔɹn sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə slɝp fɹəm ɪz mʌɡ. "ʌðɝz seɪ ɪts ə ɹɛlɪk fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðə saɪdz ɑɹ sɛd tə bi ʌv smuð stil, wɪθaʊɾ ən oʊpənɪŋ. aɪ dɪd faɪn ə kæptənz wɪɾoʊz jʌŋɡɝ sʌn u wʌns hɝɾ ə stɔɹi ʌv sʌmwʌn u faʊnd ɡɹeɪt tʃɹɛʒɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. hi dɪdn seɪ haʊ ðə læd hæd ɡɑɾən ɪn, ðoʊ."

"I haven't been able to find anyone who has gone inside," Noal continued "Some say it's haunted," Thorn said, taking a slurp from his mug. "Others say it's a relic from the Age of Legends. The sides are said to be of smooth steel, without an opening. I did find a captain's widow's younger son who once heard a story of someone who found great treasures in the tower. He didn't say how the lad had gotten in, though."

"wi noʊ haʊ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn," mæt sɛd.

"We know how to get in," Mat said.

"oʊlvɝz stɔɹi?" noʊl æsk skɛptɪkəli.

"Olver's story?" Noal asked skeptically.

"ɪts ðə bɛst wi hæv," mæt sɛd. "lʊk, ðə ɡeɪm ən ðə ɹaɪm ɑɹ əbaʊt ði æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn. pipəl nu əbaʊɾ əm wʌns. ðoʊz blʌɾi ɑɹtʃweɪz ɑɹ pɹuf ə ðæt. soʊ ðeɪ lɛf ðə ɡeɪm ən ðə ɹaɪm əz wɔɹnɪŋ."

"It's the best we have," Mat said. "Look, the game and the rhyme are about the Aelfinn and Eelfinn. People knew about them once. Those bloody archways are proof of that. So they left the game and the rhyme as warning."

"ðæt ɡeɪm kæn bi wʌn, mæt," noʊl sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz lɛðɝi tʃɪn.

"That game can't be won, Mat," Noal said, rubbing his leathery chin.

"æn ðæts ðə pɔɪn ʌv ɪt. jə nid tə tʃit."

"And that's the point of it. You need to cheat."

"bʌt meɪbi wi ʃəd tʃɹaɪ ə dil," θɔɹn sɛd, pleɪɪŋ wɪð ðə wæks tɪp ʌv ə mʌstæʃ. "ðeɪ dɪd ɡɪv jə ænsɝz tə jəɹ kwɛstʃənz."

"But maybe we should try a deal," Thorn said, playing with the waxed tip of a mustache. "They did give you answers to your questions."

"blʌɾi fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ wʌnz," mæt sɛd. hi hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə tɛl θɔɹn ən noʊl əbaʊɾ ɪz kwɛstʃənz  - hi stɪl hæd nɑt toʊld əm wʌɾ i hæɾ æskt.

"Bloody frustrating ones," Mat said. He had not wanted to tell Thorn and Noal about his questions  - he still had not told them what he had asked.

"bʌt ðeɪ dɪɾ ænsɝ," θɔɹn sɛd. "ɪt saʊnz laɪk ðeɪ hæd səm kaɪndə dil wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"But they did answer," Thorn said. "It sounds like they had some kind of deal with the Aes Sedai.

ɪf wi nu wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd ðət ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɑntəd - ðə ɹizən ðeɪ wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə bɑɹɡən- -  ðən meɪbi wi kəd tʃɹeɪɾ ɪt tə ðɛm fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn."

If we knew what it was the Aes Sedai had that the snakes and foxes wanted - the reason they were willing to bargain- -  then maybe we could trade it to them for Moiraine."

"ɪf ʃiz stɪl əlaɪv," noʊl sɛd ɡɹɪmli.

"If she's still alive," Noal said grimly.

"ʃi ɪz," θɔɹn sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. "laɪt sɛn ɪt. ʃiz tə bi əlaɪv."

"She is," Thorn said, staring straight ahead. "Light send it. She has to be alive."

"wi noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt." mæt ɡlænst ət ðoʊz fleɪmz.

"We know what they want." Mat glanced at those flames.

"wʌt?" noʊl æskt.

"What?" Noal asked.

"ʌs," mæt ɹɪplaɪd. "lʊk, ðeɪ kən si wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən. ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt tə mi, ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt tə mɔɪɹeɪn, ɪf ðət lɛɾɝ ɪz ɛni klu. ðeɪ nu ʃi wəd liv ə lɛɾɝ fəɹ ju, θɔɹn. ðeɪ nu ɪt.

"Us," Mat replied. "Look, they can see what's going to happen. They did it to me, they did it to Moiraine, if that letter is any clue. They knew she would leave a letter for you, Thorn. They knew it.

ən ðeɪ stɪl ænsɝɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənz."

And they still answered her questions."

"meɪbi ðeɪ hæd tə," θɔɹn sɛd.

"Maybe they had to," Thorn said.

"jɛs, bʌt ðeɪ doʊn əv tə ænsɝ stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝdli," mæt sɛd. "ðeɪ dɪdnt wɪð mi. ðeɪ ænsɝd noʊɪŋ ʃi wəd kʌm bæk tə ðɛm, ən ðeɪ ɡeɪv mi wʌt ðeɪ dɪd noʊɪŋ aɪd ɡɛt pʊl bæk, tu. ðeɪ wɑn mi. ðeɪ wɑn ʌs."

"Yes, but they don't have to answer straightforwardly," Mat said. "They didn't with me. They answered knowing she would come back to them, And they gave me what they did knowing I'd get pulled back, too. They want me. They want us."

"ju doʊnt noʊ ðət fəɹ sɝɾən, mæt." tɑm sɛɾ ɪz mʌɡ ʌv eɪl ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪtwin ɪz fiɾ ən ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ɪz paɪp. tə mæts ɹaɪt, mɛn tʃɪɹɾ ə daɪs ɡeɪm. "ðeɪ kən ænsɝ kwɛstʃənz, bʌt ðət dʌzn min ðeɪ noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. kəd bi laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ fɔɹtɛlɪŋz."

"You don't know that for certain, Mat." Thom set his mug of ale on the floor between his feet and got out his pipe. To Mat's right, men cheered a dice game. "They can answer questions, but that doesn't mean they know everything. Could be like Aes Sedai foretellings."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ðə kɹitʃɝz pʊt mɛmɹiz ɪndə hɪz hɛd. hi fɪɡjɝd ðeɪ wɝ ðə mɛmɹiz ə pipəl u hæd tʌtʃt ðə taʊɝ əɹ bɪn ɪndə ɪt. ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn hæd ðoʊz mɛmɹiz, ən bɝn ɪm ðeɪ pɹɑbli hæd hɪz, tu. kəd ðeɪ wɑtʃ hɪm, si θɹu hɪz aɪz?

Mat shook his head. The creatures put memories into his head. He figured they were the memories of people who had touched the tower or been into it. The Aelfinn and the Eelfinn had those memories, and burn him they probably had his, too. Could they watch him, see through his eyes?

hi wɪʃt əɡɛn fəɹ ɪz mədæljən, ðoʊ ɪt wəd də noʊ ɡʊɾ əɡɛns ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ; ðeɪ wəd nɑt juz tʃænəlɪŋ. "ðeɪ də noʊ θɪŋz, tɑm," mæt sɛd. "ðeɪɹ wɑtʃɪŋ. wi woʊn sɝpɹaɪz ðɛm."

He wished again for his medallion, though it would do no good against them. They were not Aes Sedai; they would not use channeling. "They do know things, Thom," Mat said. "They're watching. We won't surprise them."

"meɪks əm hɑɹd tə dɪfit, ðɛn," tɑm sɛd, laɪɾɪŋ ə tɪndɝ twɪɡ wɪð ðə faɪɝ, ðən juzɪŋ ɪt tə laɪɾ ɪz paɪp. "wi kænt wɪn."

"Makes them hard to defeat, then," Thom said, lighting a tinder twig with the fire, then using it to light his pipe. "We can't win."

"ənlɛs wi bɹeɪk ðə ɹulz," mæt ɹɪpiɾɪd.

"Unless we break the rules," Mat repeated.

"bʌt ðəl noʊ wʌt wɝ duɪŋ," tɑm sɛd, "ɪf wʌt jə seɪ ɪz tʃɹu. soʊ wi ʃəd tʃɹeɪd wɪð ðɛm."

"But they'll know what we're doing," Thom said, "if what you say is true. So we should trade with them."

"ænd wʌd mɔɪɹeɪn seɪ, tɑm?" mæt sɛd. "ɪn ðət lɛɾɝ jə ɹɛɾ ɛvɹi naɪt."

"And what did Moiraine say, Thom?" Mat said. "In that letter you read every night."

tɑm pʌft ɑn ɪz paɪp, ɹeɪzɪŋ ən æbsən hæn tə hɪz bɹɛs pɑkət, wɛɹ i kɛp ðə lɛɾɝ.

Thom puffed on his pipe, raising an absent hand to his breast pocket, where he kept the letter.

"ʃi sɛd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt wi nu ʌv ðə ɡeɪm."

"She said to remember what we knew of the game."

"ʃi noʊz ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ tə wɪn wən dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm," mæt sɛd. noʊ tʃɹeɪdz, tɑm, noʊ bɑɹɡənz. wi ɡoʊ ɪn faɪɾɪŋ ən wi doʊn liv əntɪl wɪv hɝ."

"She knows there's no way to win when dealing with them," Mat said. No trades, Thom, no bargains. We go in fighting and we don't leave until we have her."

tɑm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən nɑɾəd, hɪz paɪp bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə pʌf.

Thom hesitated for a moment, then nodded, his pipe beginning to puff.

kɝədʒ tə stʃɹɛŋθən," noʊl sɛd. "wɛl, wɪv ɪnʌf ə ðæt, wɪð mæts lʌk."

Courage to strengthen," Noal said. "Well, we have enough of that, with Mat's luck."

jə doʊn əv tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs, jə noʊ, noʊl," mæt sɛd. "ju hæv noʊ ɹizən tə ɹɪsk jɝsɛlf ɑn ðɪs."

You don't have to be part of this, you know, Noal," Mat said. "You have no reason to risk yourself on this."

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ," noʊl sɛd. "aɪv sin ə lɑɾ ə pleɪsəz. moʊs pleɪsəz, æktʃəli . bʌt nɛvɝ ðɪs wʌn." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ɪts sʌmθɪŋ aɪ nid tə du. ən ðæts ði ɛn ʌv ɪt."

"I'm going," Noal said. "I've seen a lot of places. Most places, actually. But never this one." He hesitated. "It's something I need to do. And that's the end of it."

"vɛɹi wɛl," mæt sɛd.

"Very well," Mat said.

"faɪɝ tə blaɪnd," noʊl sɛd. "wʌt də wi hæv?"

"Fire to blind," Noal said. "What do we have?"

"læntɝnz ən tɔɹtʃɪz," mæt sɛd, nɑkɪŋ ɪz fʊɾ əɡɛns ðə sæk bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ. "æn səm ə ðoʊz faɪɹstɪks fɹəm ɑlʌdʒɹə, soʊ wi kən laɪt ðɛm. ə fju sɝpɹaɪzəz fɹəm hɝ, tu."

"Lanterns and torches," Mat said, knocking his foot against the sack beside his chair. "And some of those firesticks from Aludra, so we can light them. A few surprises from her, too."

"faɪɹwɝks?" noʊl æskt.

"Fireworks?" Noal asked.

"æn ə fju ʌv ðoʊz ɪksploʊɾɪŋ sɪləndɝz wi juzd əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. ʃi kɔlz əm ɹɔɹstɪks."

"And a few of those exploding cylinders we used against the Seanchan. She calls them roarsticks."

θɔɹn wɪsəld. "ʃi lɛt juv sʌm?"

Thorn whistled. "She let you have some?"

"tu. wən aɪ pɹizɛntəɾ əɹ wɪð ɪleɪnz əɡɹimənt, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə lemi hæv ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ aɪ æsk fɔɹ." mæt ɡɹɪməst. "ʃi wɑntəd tə kʌm əlɔŋ tə laɪt ðɛm. hɝsɛlf! bɝn mi, bʌt ðət wɑz ə tʌf ɑɹɡjəmən tə ɛnd. bʌt wiv ɡɑɾ ə hoʊl lɑɾ ə naɪtfloʊɝz." hi tæp ðə sæk bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ wɪð ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz fʊt.

"Two. When I presented her with Elayne's agreement, she was ready to let me have almost anything I asked for." Mat grimaced. "She wanted to come along to light them. Herself! Burn me, but that was a tough argument to end. But we've got a whole lot of nightflowers." He tapped the sack beside his chair with the edge of his foot.

"ju bɹɔt ðɛm?" θɔɹn æskt.

"You brought them?" Thorn asked.

"aɪ wɑntəd tə kip əm kloʊs," mæt sɛd. "ænd ʃi oʊnli ɡeɪv əm tə mi tədeɪ. ðəɹ nɑt gɑnə ɪksploʊd baɪ æksəɾənt, θɔɹn. ðət dʌzn hæpən vɛɹi ɔfən."

"I wanted to keep them close," Mat said. "And she only gave them to me today. They're not going to explode by accident, Thorn. That doesn't happen very often."

"wɛl ət lis muv əm bæk fɹəm ðə hɑɹθ!" θɔɹn sɛd. hi ɡlænst əɾ ɪz paɪp ən kɝst, ðən skuɾɪd ɪz tʃɛɹ ə fju ɪntʃəz fɹəm mæt.

"Well at least move them back from the hearth!" Thorn said. He glanced at his pipe and cursed, then scooted his chair a few inches from Mat.

"nɛkst," noʊl sɛd, "mjuzɪk tə dæzəl."

"Next," Noal said, "music to dazzle."

"aɪ ɡɑɾ əs ə vɝaɪəɾi," θɔɹn sɛd. "aɪl bɹɪŋ maɪ hɑɹp ən flut, bʌɾ aɪ faʊn əs səm hæn dʒɹʌmz ən hæn sɪmbəlz. ðeɪ kən bi stʃɹæp tə ðə saɪɾ ə jəɹ lɛɡ ən hɪt wɪð wʌn hænd. aɪ ɔlsoʊ bɑɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə flut." hi aɪd mæt. "ə sɪmpəl wʌn, dɪzaɪn fəɹ ðoʊz wɪð θɪk, sloʊ fɪŋɡɝz."

"I got us a variety," Thorn said. "I'll bring my harp and flute, but I found us some hand drums and hand cymbals. They can be strapped to the side of your leg and hit with one hand. I also bought an extra flute." He eyed Mat. "A simple one, designed for those with thick, slow fingers."

mæt snɔɹɾɪd.

Mat snorted.

"æn faɪnəli, aɪɝn tə baɪnd," noʊl sɛd, slaɪɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ə pæk ə hɪz oʊn. ɪt klɪŋk feɪnli əz i əntaɪd ðə tɑp, ðə kɑntɛns ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə dip ɔɹənʒ hɑɹθlaɪt. "ə sɛɾ ə θɹoʊɪŋ naɪvz fəɹ itʃ ʌv əs ən tu ʃɔɹtsɝdz. itʃ ə pjʊɹ aɪɝn, noʊ stil. aɪ ɡɑɾ əs səm tʃeɪnz, tu, ən ə bæn ʌv aɪɝn tə klɪp ɝaʊn ðə bʌɾ ə mæts spɪɹ. ɪt maɪt θɹoʊ ðə weɪɾ ɔf, ðoʊ."

"And finally, iron to bind," Noal said, sliding forward a pack of his own. It clinked faintly as he untied the top, the contents reflecting the deep orange hearthlight. "A set of throwing knives for each of us and two shortswords. Each of pure iron, no steel. I got us some chains, too, and a band of iron to clip around the butt of Mat's spear. It might throw the weight off, though."

"aɪl teɪk ɪt," mæt sɛd.

"I'll take it," Mat said.

noʊl dɪɾ ʌp ɪz pæk əɡɛn, ən ðə θɹi ʌv əm sæt bɪfɔɹ ðə hɑɹθ fəɹ ə taɪm. ɪn ə weɪ, ðiz θɪŋz ðeɪd ɡæðɝd wɝ ən ɪluʒən. ə weɪ tə ɹiəʃʊɹ ðɛmsɛlvz ðət ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə pɹipɛɹ.

Noal did up his pack again, and the three of them sat before the hearth for a time. In a way, these things they'd gathered were an illusion. A way to reassure themselves that they were doing something to prepare.

bʌt mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðoʊz twɪstəd pleɪsəz bɪɑn ðə ɡeɪtweɪz, ði æŋɡəlz ðət wɝ nɑt ɹaɪt, ði ənnætʃɹəl lændskeɪp. ðə kɹitʃɝz kɔl sneɪks ən fɑksəz kəz ðeɪ dɪfaɪd stændɝd dɪskɹɪpʃən.

But Mat remembered those twisted places beyond the gateways, the angles that were not right, the unnatural landscape. The creatures called snakes and foxes because they defied standard description.

ðət pleɪs wɑz ənʌðɝ wɝld. ðə pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz i dɪd wɪð θɔɹn ən noʊl maɪt hɛlp' bʌt ðeɪ maɪɾ ɔlsoʊ bi jusləs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ stɛpt ɪndə ðət taʊɝ. ɪt fɛlt laɪk nɑt noʊɪŋ ɪf jə hæd ðə ɹaɪɾ æntɪdoʊɾ əntɪl æftɝ ðə sneɪks tiθ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi klæmp daʊn ɑn jəɹ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, hi beɪd ði ʌðɝ tu ə ɡʊd naɪt. noʊl wɑntəd tə hɛd bæk tə ðə bænz kæmp, wɪtʃ wɑz naʊ oʊnli ə tɛn-mɪnət ɹaɪd fɹəm ðə sɪɾi. θɔɹn əɡɹid tə ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm, ən ðeɪ tʊk mæts pæk fʊl ə naɪtfloʊɝz - ðoʊ boʊθ mɛn lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ wəd ɹæðɝ bi kæɹiɪŋ ə sæk fʊl ə spaɪɾɝz.

That place was another world. The preparations he did with Thorn and Noal might help' but they might also be useless. There was no telling until they stepped into that tower. It felt like not knowing if you had the right antidote until after the snake's teeth were already clamped down on your Eventually, he bade the other two a good night. Noal wanted to head back to the Band's camp, which was now only a ten-minute ride from the city. Thorn agreed to go with him, and they took Mat's pack full of nightflowers - though both men looked as if they would rather be carrying a sack full of spiders.

mæt bɛltəɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑn oʊvɝ ɪz koʊt, tʊk ʌp ɪz stæf, ðən hɛɾəd bæk təwɔɹɾ ɪz ɪn. hi dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ dɝɛkli ðɛɹ, ðoʊ, ən ɪnstɛd faʊn hɪmsɛlf tʃɹeɪlɪŋ θɹu ði æliz ən stʃɹits. ʃæntiz ən tɛns hæd spɹʌŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd sɑləd bɪldɪŋz əz ðə sɪɾi-aʊtsaɪd-ðə-sɪti spɹɛɾ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz, laɪk moʊld ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑn ə loʊf ə bɹɛd.

Mat belted his sword on over his coat, took up his staff, then headed back toward his inn. He did not go directly there, though, and instead found himself trailing through the alleys and streets. Shanties and tents had sprung up beside solid buildings as the city-outside-the-city spread along the walls, like mold growing on a loaf of bread.

ðə skaɪ wɑz dɑɹk, bʌt ðə naɪt wɑz stɪl bɪzi, taʊts kɔlɪŋ fɹəm wɪðɪn ðə lɪt dɔɹweɪz ʌv ɪnz.

The sky was dark, but the night was still busy, touts calling from within the lit doorways of inns.

mæt meɪd ʃʊɹ ðə ʃɔɹtsɔɝd wɑz vɪzəbəl. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni hu wəd θɪŋk tə ɪksplɔɪɾ ə loʊn wɑndɝɝ ət naɪt, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz, wɛɹ ði ɑɹm ə ðə lɔ wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɑn ðə flæbi saɪd.

Mat made sure the shortsword was visible. There were many who would think to exploit a lone wanderer at night, particularly outside the city walls, where the arm of the law was a little on the flabby side.

ði ɛɹ smɛld ʌv ɪmpɛndɪŋ ɹeɪn, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔfən dɪd ðiz deɪz. hi wɪʃt ɪt wəd ɡoʊ ɑn ən stɔɹm əɹ blʌɾi klɪɹ ʌp. ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf ði ɛɹ wɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɪts bɹɛθ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ. ə bloʊ ðət nɛvɝ fɛl, ə bɛl ðət nɛvɝ ɹæŋ, ə sɛɾ ə daɪs ðət nɛvɝ stɑp spɪnɪŋ. dʒʌs laɪk ðə wʌnz ðət θʌndɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd.

The air smelled of impending rain, but it often did these days. He wished it would go on and storm or bloody clear up. It felt as if the air were holding its breath, waiting for something. A blow that never fell, a bell that never rang, a set of dice that never stopped spinning. Just like the ones that thundered in his head.

hi fɛlt ət ðə lɛɾɝ fɹəm vɛɹɪn ɪn ɪz pɑkət. wəd ðə daɪs stɑp ɪf i oʊpən ɪt? meɪbi ɪt wɑz əbaʊt ðə ɡboʊləm. ɪf i dɪd nɑt ɹɪtʃɹiv ɪz mədæljən fɹəm ɪleɪn sun, ðə θɪŋ wɑz laɪkli tə faɪn ɪm ən ɹɪp ɪz ɪnsaɪdz aʊt.

He felt at the letter from Verin in his pocket. Would the dice stop if he opened it? Maybe it was about the gbolam. If he did not retrieve his medallion from Elayne soon, the thing was likely to find him and rip his insides out.

blʌɾi æʃəz. hi fɛlt laɪk ɡoʊɪŋ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, fɝɡɛɾɪŋ u hi wɑz -  ən u pipəl θɔɾ i wɑz - fəɹ ə waɪl. bʌɾ ɪf i ɡɑt dʒɹʌŋk, hi wɑz laɪkli tə lɛɾ ɪz feɪs ʃoʊ baɪ æksəɾənt. pɝhæps bɪɡɪn tə tɔk əbaʊɾ u hi ɹɪli wɑz. jə nɛvɝ kəd tɛl wʌɾ ə mæn wəd də wən i wɑz dʒɹʌŋk, ivən ɪf ðət mæn wɑz jəɹ oʊn sɛlf.

Bloody ashes. He felt like going drinking, forgetting who he was -  and who people thought he was - for a while. But if he got drunk, he was likely to let his face show by accident. Perhaps begin to talk about who he really was. You never could tell what a man would do when he was drunk, even if that man was your own self.

hi meɪɾ ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts ən ɪndə ðə nu sɪɾi. ði ɛɹ bɪɡæn tə mɪst wɪð sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɑz nɑt kwaɪt ɹeɪn, əz ɪf ðə skaɪ hæd lɪsən tə hɪz ɹæn ən hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə əlaʊ ə lɪɾəl sniz tə spɹeɪ daʊn ɑn hɪm.

He made his way through the city gates and into the New City. The air began to mist with something that was not quite rain, as if the sky had listened to his rant and had decided to allow a little sneeze to spray down on him.

wʌndɝfəl, hi θɔt, blʌɾi wʌndɝfəl.

Wonderful, he thought, bloody wonderful.

ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz sun ɡɹu wɛt fɹəm ðə nɑt-ɹeɪn, ən ðə stʃɹitlɑmps ɡloʊd wɪð bɔlz ə veɪpɝəs heɪz. mæt hʌŋkɝd daʊn, skɑɹf stɪl kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz feɪs əz ɪf i wɝ ə blʌɾi ilmən. hæɾ i nɑt bɪn tu hɑɾ oʊnli ə lɪɾəl bɪɾ əɡoʊ?

The paving stones soon grew wet from the not-rain, and the streetlamps glowed with balls of vaporous haze. Mat hunkered down, scarf still covering his face as if he were a bloody Aielman. Had he not been too hot only a little bit ago?

hi wɑz əz iɡɝ əz tɑm tə muv ɑn ən faɪn mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi hæd meɪɾ ə mɛs ə hɪz laɪf, bʌt mæt səpoʊzd i oʊɾ əɹ fəɹ ðæt. bɛɾɝ tə lɪv ɪn ðɪs mɛs ðən tə bi tʃɹæp bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, lɪvɪŋ ə bɔɹɪŋ laɪf wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ haʊ bɔɹɪŋ ɪt wɑz. mæt wɑz nɑt laɪk pɛɹɪn, hu hæd mun oʊvɝ livɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæɾ ivən ɡɑɾən tə bɛɹ-aɪən. ən ɪmədʒ ə pɛɹɪn flæʃt ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən mæt bænɪʃt ɪt.

He was as eager as Thom to move on and find Moiraine. She had made a mess of his life, but Mat supposed he owed her for that. Better to live in this mess than to be trapped back in the Two Rivers, living a boring life without realizing how boring it was. Mat was not like Perrin, who had mooned over leaving the Two Rivers before they had even gotten to Baer-Ion. An image of Perrin flashed in his head, and Mat banished it.

ən wʌɾ ə ɹænd? mæt sɔ hɪm sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə faɪn tʃɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət ðə flɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə dɑɹk ɹum, ə sɪŋɡəl læmp flɪkɝɪŋ. hi lʊkt wɔɹn ən ɪɡzɔstəd, hɪz aɪz waɪd, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹɪm. mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd tə dɪspɛl ðəɾ ɪmədʒ əz wɛl. pʊɹ ɹænd. ðə mæn pɹɑbli θɔɾ i wɑz ə blʌɾi blækfɹəɾ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ baɪ naʊ, nɔɪŋ ɑn pɪnəkoʊnz. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪkli ə blækfɹət ðət wɑntəd tə lɪv bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

And what of Rand? Mat saw him sitting on a fine chair, staring down at the floor in front of himself in a dark room, a single lamp flickering. He looked worn and exhausted, his eyes wide, his expression grim. Mat shook his head to dispel that image as well. Poor Rand. The man probably thought he was a bloody blackferret or something by now, gnawing on pinecones. But it was likely a blackferret that wanted to live back in the Two Rivers.

noʊ, mæt dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɡoʊ bæk. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tuɑn bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. laɪt, wɛl, hi wəɾ əv tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt tə də wɪð tuɑn. bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi ɹɪɾ ə hɝ. ɪf ʃi wɝ stɪl wɪð hɪm, hi wəd lɛɾ əɹ kɔl ɪm tɔɪ wɪθaʊt kəmpleɪnɪŋ. wɛl, nɑt mʌtʃ ɛniweɪ.

No, Mat did not want to go back. There was no Tuon back in the Two Rivers. Light, well, he would have to figure out what to do with Tuon. But he did not want to be rid of her. If she were still with him, he would let her call him Toy without complaining. Well, not much anyway.

mɔɪɹeɪn fɝst. hi wɪʃt i nu mɔɹ əbaʊt ði æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn ən ðɛɹ blʌɾi taʊɝ.

Moiraine first. He wished he knew more about the Aelfinn and Eelfinn and their bloody tower.

noʊbɑdi nu əbaʊɾ ɪt, noʊbɑdi spoʊk mɔɹ ðən lɛdʒənz, noʊbɑdi hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl tə seɪ. . . .

Nobody knew about it, nobody spoke more than legends, nobody had anything useful to say. . . .

. . . noʊbɑdi bʌt bɝdʒɪt. mæt stɑpt ɪn ðə stʃɹit. bɝdʒɪt. ʃi hæd bɪn ðə wʌn tə tɛl oʊlvɝ haʊ tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ. haʊ hæd ʃi noʊn?

. . . nobody but Birgitte. Mat stopped in the street. Birgitte. She had been the one to tell Olver how to get into the Tower. How had she known?

kɝsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ə ful, hi tɝn təwɔɹd ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. ðə stʃɹits wɝ ɛmptiɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹæfɪk ðət hæd bɝɾənd əm bɪfɔɹ ði ɔlmoʊst-ɹeɪn bɪɡæn. sun mæt fɛlt i hæd ðə hoʊl sɪɾi tə hɪmsɛlf; ivən ðə kʌt-pɝsɪz ən bɛɡɝz wɪθdʒɹu.

Cursing himself for a fool, he turned toward the Inner City. The streets were emptying of the traffic that had burdened them before the almost-rain began. Soon Mat felt he had the whole city to himself; even the cut-purses and beggars withdrew.

fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðət pʊɾ ɪm ɑn ɛdʒ mɔɹ ðən biɪŋ stɛɹɾ æt. ɪt wɑz nɑt nætʃɹəl. sʌmwʌn ʃʊɾə tʃɹaɪɾ ət lis tə blʌɾi ʃædoʊ hɪm tə si ɪf i wɑz wɝθ pɪkɪŋ ɔf. wʌns əɡɛn, hi lɔŋ fəɹ ɪz mədæljən. hi hæd bɪn ən ɪɾiət tə ɡɪv ðəɾ əweɪ. bɛɾɝ tə hæv kʌɾ ɔf ɪz oʊn blʌɾi hæn ən ɔfɝd ðət tə ɪleɪn əz peɪmənt! wɑz ðə ɡoʊləm ðɛɹ, ɪn ðət dɑɹknəs, sʌmwɛɹ?

For some reason, that put him on edge more than being stared at. It was not natural. Someone should have tried at least to bloody shadow him to see if he was worth picking off. Once again, he longed for his medallion. He had been an idiot to give that away. Better to have cut off his own bloody hand and offered that to Elayne as payment! Was the gholam there, in that darkness, somewhere?

ðəɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn tʌfs ɑn ðə stʃɹit. sɪɾiz wɝ fʊl ə ðɛm. ðət wɑz pɹæktəkli wʌn ə ðə blʌɾi ɹɪkwaɪɹməns fəɹ ə sɪɾi. ə taʊn hɔl, ə fju ɪnz ən ə tævɝn, ən sɛvɹəl blʌnt-feɪs fɛloʊz huz oʊnli dɪzaɪɝ wɑz tə paʊn jə ɪndə ðə mʌɾ ən spɛn jəɹ kɔɪn ɑn dʒɹɪŋk ən wɪmən- hi pæst ə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ən hɛɾəd θɹu ðə meɪsənz ɡeɪɾ ɪndə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, ðə waɪɾ ɑɹtʃweɪ ɔlmoʊst simɪŋ tə ɡloʊ, ɹeɪn-slɪk ɪn ðə fæntəm laɪɾ ə ðə klaʊɾəd mun. mæts kɔɹɾɝstæf nɑkt əɡɛns ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ðə ɡeɪt ɡɑɹdz wɝ hʌɾəld ən kwaɪəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks, laɪk stætʃuz, nɑt mɛn əɾ ɔl. ði ɪntaɪɝ pleɪs fɛlt laɪk ə tum. ə weɪz pæs ðə ɡeɪt, hi pæst ən æliweɪ, ən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi θɔɾ i kəd si ə ɡɹup ə ʃæɾoʊi fɔɹmz ɪnsaɪd. tɔl bɪldɪŋz ɹoʊz ɑn iðɝ saɪd, ɡɹæn oʊɡiɝ meɪsənɹi. ə ɡɹʌn saʊndəd fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ði æliweɪ. "ə ɹɑbɝi?" mæt sɛd wɪð ɹɪlif.

There should have been toughs on the street. Cities were full of them. That was practically one of the bloody requirements for a city. A town hall, a few inns and a tavern, and several blunt-faced fellows whose only desire was to pound you into the mud and spend your coin on drink and women- He passed a courtyard and headed through the Mason's Gate into the Inner City, the white archway almost seeming to glow, rain-slick in the phantom light of the clouded moon. Mat's quarterstaff knocked against the paving stones. The gate guards were huddled and quiet in their cloaks, Like statues, not men at all. The entire place felt like a tomb. A ways past the gate, he passed an alleyway, and hesitated. He thought he could see a group of shadowy forms inside. Tall buildings rose on either side, grand Ogier masonry. A grunt sounded from inside the alleyway. "A robbery?" Mat said with relief.

ə hʌlkɪŋ fɪɡjɝ lʊk bæk aʊɾ ə ði æliweɪ. munlaɪt ɹɪvil fɛloʊ wɪð dɑɹk aɪz ən ə lɔŋ kloʊk. hi sim stʌn tə faɪn mæt ndɪŋ ðɛɹ. hi pɔɪntəd wɪð ə θɪk-fɪŋɡɝd hænd, ən θɹi ʌv ɪz kəmpænjənz meɪd fəɹ mæt.

A hulking figure looked back out of the alleyway. Moonlight revealed fellow with dark eyes and a long cloak. He seemed stunned to find Mat nding there. He pointed with a thick-fingered hand, and three of his companions made for Mat.

mæt ɹɪlækst, waɪpɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊ fɹi ʌv ɹeɪnwɔɾɝ. soʊ ðəɹ wɝ fʊtpædz aʊt ðɪs naɪt. wʌɾ ə ɹɪlif. hi hæd bɪn dʒʌmpɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ!

Mat relaxed, wiping his brow free of rainwater. So there were footpads out this night. What a relief. He had been jumping at nothing!

ə θʌɡ swʌŋ ɪz kʌdʒəl ət mæt. mæt hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔɹtsɔɝɾ ɑn ðə ɹaɪt saɪɾ ɪntɛnʃənəli; ðə θʌɡ tʊk ðə beɪt, əsumɪŋ ðət mæt wəd muv tə dʒɹɔ ðə wɛpən.

A thug swung his cudgel at Mat. Mat had worn the shortsword on the right side intentionally; the thug took the bait, assuming that Mat would move to draw the weapon.

ɪnstɛd, mæt bɹɔɾ ʌp ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf swɪfli, snæpɪŋ ðə bʌɾ əɡɛns ðə mænz lɛɡ. ðə fʊtpæd stʌmbəld, ən mæt swʌŋ ɪndə ðə mænz hɛd. ðə dʒɹɪzəl, wɪtʃ wɑz nɪɹli ə pɹɑpɝ ɹeɪn baɪ naʊ, spɹeɪɾ ɔf ðə kʌtpɝs əz i fɛl, tʃɹɪpɪŋ wʌn ə hɪz kəmpænjənz.

Instead, Mat brought up the quarterstaff swiftly, snapping the butt against the man's leg. The footpad stumbled, and Mat swung into the man's head. The drizzle, which was nearly a proper rain by now, sprayed off the cutpurse as he fell, tripping one of his companions.

mæt stɛp bæk ən slæm ðə tɑp ə ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf daʊn ɑn ðə hɛɾ ə ðə tʃɹɪpɪŋ θʌɡ.

Mat stepped back and slammed the top of the quarterstaff down on the head of the tripping thug.

hi wɛn daʊn ɑn tɑp ə hɪz kəmpænjən. ðə θɝd mæn lʊk bæk təwɔɹɾ ɪz liɾɝ, hu hɛl tə ðə kɑlɝ ʌv ə ɡæŋli mæn mæt kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊɾ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz. mæt tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə lip oʊvɝ ðə smɔl paɪl ʌv ʌnkɑnʃəs θʌɡz, swɪŋɪŋ ət ðə θɝd mæn. ðə fʊtpæd bɹɔɾ ɪz kʌdʒəl ʌp tə pɹətɛkt ɪz hɛd, soʊ mæt slæmd ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf ɪndə ðə mænz fʊt. hi ðən swʌŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf, nɑkɪŋ əsaɪd ðə θɝd mænz wik pɛɹi, ən dʒɹɑpt ɪm wɪð ə bloʊ tə ðə feɪs.

He went down on top of his companion. The third man looked back toward his leader, who held to the collar of a gangly man Mat could barely make out in the shadows. Mat took the opportunity to leap over the small pile of unconscious thugs, swinging at the third man. The footpad brought his cudgel up to protect his head, so Mat slammed his quarterstaff into the man's foot. He then swung the quarterstaff, knocking aside the third man's weak parry, and dropped him with a blow to the face.

mæt kæʒəwəli flɪpt ə naɪf təwɔɹd ðə liɾɝ ə ðə ɡæŋ, hu wɑz tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ðə liɾɝ ɡɝɡəld, stʌmbəld ɪn ðə dʒɹɪzəl, klɔɪŋ ət ðə naɪf ɪn ɪz nɛk. ði ʌðɝz mæt wəd liv ʌnkɑnʃəs - pʊɹ fulz, meɪbi ðeɪ wəd teɪk ðɪs wɔɹnɪŋ ən ɹəfɔɹm.

Mat casually flipped a knife toward the leader of the gang, who was charging forward. The leader gurgled, stumbled in the drizzle, clawing at the knife in his neck. The others Mat would leave unconscious - poor fools, maybe they would take this warning and reform.

mæt stɛp tə ðə saɪɾ əz ðə liɾɝ stʌmbəl pæst, ðən faɪnəli kɑl-læpst ɑn tɑp ə hɪz θɹi kəmpænjənz. mæt kɪkt ɪm oʊvɝ, pʊld aʊt ðə naɪf, ðən klin ɪt. faɪnəli, hi ɡlænst ət ðə vɪktəm ə ðə ɹɑbɝi. "ʃʊɹ æm ɡlæd tə si ju," mæt sɛd. "ju . . . jə ɑɹ?" ðə mæn æskt.

Mat stepped to the side as the leader stumbled past, then finally col-lapsed on top of his three companions. Mat kicked him over, pulled out the knife, then cleaned it. Finally, he glanced at the victim of the robbery. "Sure am glad to see you," Mat said. "You . . . you are?" the man asked.

"ʃʊɹ æm," mæt sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. "aɪ θɔt ðə θivz wɝ nɑɾ aʊt tənaɪt. ə sɪɾi wɪθaʊt kʌtpɝsɪz, wɛl, ðæts laɪk ə fild wɪθaʊt widz. ən ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ widz, wʌt wəd jə niɾ ə fɑɹmɝ fɔɹ? blʌɾi ɪnhɑspəɾəbəl, aɪ tɛl ju."

"Sure am," Mat said, standing up straight. "I thought the thieves were not out tonight. A city without cutpurses, well, that's like a field without weeds. And if there were no weeds, what would you need a farmer for? Bloody inhospitable, I tell you."

ðə ɹɛskjud mæn stʌmbəl fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn ʃeɪki fit. hi sim kɑn-fjuz baɪ wʌt mæt hæd sɛd, bʌɾ i skɹæmbəld ʌp, teɪkɪŋ mæts hænd "θæŋk ju!" ðə mæn hæɾ ə neɪzəl vɔɪs. "θæŋk jə soʊ, soʊ mʌtʃ." ɪn ðə feɪn munlaɪt, mæt kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊɾ ə waɪd feɪs wɪð bʌk tiθ ətɑp ən ɔkwɝdli θɪn bɑɾi.

The rescued man stumbled forward on shaky feet. He seemed con-fused by what Mat had said, but he scrambled up, taking Mat's hand "Thank you!" The man had a nasal voice. "Thank you so, so much." In the faint moonlight, Mat could barely make out a wide face with buck teeth atop an awkwardly thin body.

mæt ʃɹʌɡd, sɛɾɪŋ əsaɪɾ ɪz stæf ən ənwaɪndɪŋ ɪz skɑɹf__-wɪtʃ wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ sɑɾən - ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹɪŋ ɪt fɹi. "aɪd steɪ əweɪ fɹəm tʃɹævlɪŋ baɪ jɝsɛlf ət naɪt, ɪf aɪ wɝ ju, fɹɛnd."

Mat shrugged, setting aside his staff and unwinding his scarf__-which was getting sodden - and beginning to wring it free. "I'd stay away from traveling by yourself at night, if I were you, friend."

ðə mæn skwɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. "ju!" hi sɛd, vɔɪs nɪɹli ə skwik.

The man squinted in the darkness. "You!" he said, voice nearly a squeak.

mæt ɡɹoʊnd. "blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! kæn aɪ ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ wɪθaʊt__"

Mat groaned. "Blood and bloody ashes! Can't I go anywhere without__"

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz ðə mæn lʌnʒd, ə dæɡɝ flæʃɪŋ ɪn ðə feɪn munlaɪt. mæt kɝst, ən snæpt ɪz skɑɹf ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ðə dæɡɝ hɪt ðə klɔθ ɪnstɛɾ ə mæts ɡʌt, ən mæt kwɪkli twɪstəɾ ɪz hænz, taɪɪŋ ði əsæsənz dæɡɝ ɪn lɛŋθs ə klɔθ.

He cut off as the man lunged, a dagger flashing in the faint moonlight. Mat cursed, and snapped his scarf in front of him. The dagger hit the cloth instead of Mat's gut, and Mat quickly twisted his hands, tying the assassin's dagger in lengths of cloth.

ðə mæn jɛlpt, ən mæt ɹilis ðə skɑɹf ən pʊld aʊɾ ə pɛɹ ə naɪvz, wʌn ɪn itʃ hænd, ɹilisɪŋ əm baɪ ɹiflɛks. ðeɪ tʊk ði əsæsən ɪn ði aɪz. wʌn ɪn itʃ aɪ. laɪt! mæt hæd nɑt bɪn eɪmɪŋ fəɹ ði aɪz.

The man yelped, and Mat released the scarf and pulled out a pair of knives, one in each hand, releasing them by reflex. They took the assassin in the eyes. One in each eye. Light! Mat had not been aiming for the eyes.

ðə mæn kəlæps tə ðə wɛt peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz.

The man collapsed to the wet paving stones.

mæt stʊd bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt. "mʌðɝz mɪlk ɪn ə kʌp! mʌðɝz blʌɾi mɪlk!" hi ɡɹæbd ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf, ɡlænsɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, bʌt ðə ɡlumi stʃɹit wɑz ɛmpti. "aɪ ɹɛskjud ju. aɪ ɹɛskjud ju, ən jə tʃɹaɪ tə stæb mi?"

Mat stood breathing in and out. "Mother's milk in a cup! Mother's bloody milk!" He grabbed his quarterstaff, glancing about him, but the gloomy street was empty. "I rescued you. I rescued you, and you try to stab me?"

mæt nɛl daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə kɔɹps. ðɛn, ɡɹɪmli sɝɾən wʌɾ i wəd faɪnd, hi fɪʃt ɪn ðə mænz paʊtʃ. hi keɪm aʊt wɪð ə kʌpəl ə kɔɪnz -  ɡoʊl kɔɪnz - ən ə foʊldəd-ʌp pis ə peɪpɝ. munlaɪt ɹɪvil mæts feɪs ɑn ɪt. hi kɹɪŋkəl ðə peɪpɝ ən ʃʌvd ɪɾ ɪn ɪz pɑkət.

Mat knelt down beside the corpse. Then, grimly certain what he would find, he fished in the man's pouch. He came out with a couple of coins -  gold coins - and a folded-up piece of paper. Moonlight revealed Mat's face on it. He crinkled the paper and shoved it in his pocket.

wʌn ɪn itʃ blʌɾi aɪ. bɛɾɝ ðən ðə mæn dɪzɝvd. mæt ɹɛtaɪɾ ɪz skɑɹf, ɡɹæbd ɪz naɪvz, ðən wɔkt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹit, wɪʃɪŋ i hæd lɛf ði əsæsən tə hɪz feɪt.

One in each bloody eye. Better than the man deserved. Mat retied his scarf, grabbed his knives, then walked out onto the street, wishing he had left the assassin to his fate.

bɝdʒɪt foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə mɑɹbəl pɪlɝ ən wɑtʃɪŋ əz ɪleɪn sæɾ ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ən ivnɪŋ pɹɛzənteɪʃən ʌv "pleɪɝz." ɡɹups laɪk ðɪs -  æktɪŋ aʊt stɔɹiz - hæd bɪkʌm vɛɹi pɑpjəlɝ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən wɝ naʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ətʃiv ðə seɪm səksɛs ɪn ændɝ. wʌn ə ðə pæləs hɔlz, wɛɹ bɑɹdz pɝfɔɹmd, hæd bɪn ədæptəd tə əlaʊ ðə pleɪɝz tə ækt aʊt ðɛɹ stɔɹiz.

Birgitte folded her arms, leaning against a marble pillar and watching as Elayne sat enjoying an evening presentation of "players." Groups like this -  acting out stories - had become very popular in Cairhien, and were now trying to achieve the same success in Andor. One of the palace halls, where bards performed, had been adapted to allow the players to act out their stories.

bɝdʒɪt ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. wʌt wɑz ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv æktɪŋ aʊt feɪk stɔɹiz.

Birgitte shook her head. What was the good of acting out fake stories.

waɪ nɑt ɡoʊ lɪv ə fju stɔɹiz ə jəɹ oʊn? bɪsaɪdz, ʃid pɹəfɝ ə bɑɹɾ ɛni deɪ. hɛlpfəli ðɪs fæʃən ə siɪŋ "pleɪɝz" wəd daɪ kwɪkli. ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ stɔɹi wɑz ə ɹitɛlɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹædʒɪk mɛɹɪdʒ ən dɛθ ə ðə pɹɪnsɛs wælɪʃən, sleɪn baɪ bists ə ðə ʃædoʊ. bɝdʒɪt wɑz fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðə bæləd ðət ðə pleɪɝz hæɾ ədæptəd tə fɔɹm ðɛɹ stɔɹi. ɪn fækt, ðeɪ sæŋ pɑɹts ʌv ɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə pɝfɔɹməns. ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl haʊ lɪɾəl ðət sɔŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz. səm dɪfɹənt neɪmz, ə fju dɪfɹənt noʊts, bʌt ðə seɪm oʊvɝɔl. mʌtʃ laɪk əɹ oʊn laɪvz. ɹɪpiɾɪd oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ, bʌt wɪð lɪɾəl vɛɹieɪʃənz. səmtaɪmz ʃi wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ. səmtaɪmz ʃi wɑz ə fɔɹəst wʊmən, wɪð noʊ fɔɹməl mɪlətɛɹi tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ʃid bɪn ə dʒɛnɝəl wʌns əɹ twaɪs, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ʃid ɹæðɝ liv ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ dʒɑb fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls.

Why not go live a few stories of your own? Besides, she'd prefer a bard any day. Helpfully this fashion of seeing "players" would die quickly. This particular story was a retelling of the tragic marriage and death of the Princess Walishen, slain by beasts of the Shadow. Birgitte was familiar with the ballad that the players had adapted to form their story. In fact, they sang parts of it during the performance. It was remarkable how little that song had changed over the years. Some different names, a few different notes, but the same overall. Much like her own lives. Repeated over and over, but with little variations. Sometimes she was a soldier. Sometimes she was a forest woman, with no formal military training. She'd been a general once or twice, unfortunately. She'd rather leave that particular job for someone else.

ʃid bɪn ə ɡɑɹd, ə noʊbəl θif, ə leɪɾi, ə pɛzənt, ə kɪlɝ ən ə seɪvjɝ. bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ bɪn ə wɔɹɾɝ. ði ʌnfəmɪljɛɹəɾi dɪdn bɑðɝ hɝ; ɪn moʊst ə hɝ lɪvz, ʃi hæd noʊ nɑlədʒ ʌv wʌt hæd kʌm bɪfɔɹ. wʌt ʃi kəd dʒɹɔ fɹəm əɹ pɹiviəs laɪvz naʊ wɑz ə bun, jɛs, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə ðoʊz mɛmɹiz.

She'd been a guard, a noble thief, a lady, a peasant, a killer and a savior. But she had never before been a Warder. The unfamiliarity didn't bother her; in most of her lives, she had no knowledge of what had come before. What she could draw from her previous lives now was a boon, yes, but she had no right to those memories.

ðət dɪdn stɑp əɹ hɑɹt fɹəm twɪstɪŋ itʃ taɪm wʌn ə ðoʊz mɛmɹiz feɪɾəd. laɪt! ɪf ʃi kʊdn bi wɪð ɡeɪɾəl ðɪs taɪm ɝaʊnd, kʊdnt ʃi ət list ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɪm? ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðə pæɾɝn dɪdnt noʊ wʌt tə də wɪð hɝ. ʃid bɪn fɔɹst ɪndə ðɪs laɪf, ʃʌvɪŋ ʌðɝ θɹɛdz əsaɪd, teɪkɪŋ ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd pleɪs. ðə pæɾɝn wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wiv əɹ ɪn. wʌt wəd hæpən wən ɔl ə ðə mɛmɹiz feɪɾəd? wəd ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝ weɪkɪŋ ʌp əz ən ədʌlt wɪð noʊ hɪstɝi? ðə θɔt tɛɹəfaɪɾ əɹ əz noʊ bæɾəlfild ɛvɝ hæd.

That didn't stop her heart from twisting each time one of those memories faded. Light! If she couldn't be with Gaidal this time around, couldn't she at least remember him? It was as if the Pattern didn't know what to do with her. She'd been forced into this life, shoving other threads aside, taking an unexpected place. The Pattern was trying to weave her in. What would happen when all of the memories faded? Would she remember waking up as an adult with no history? The thought terrified her as no battlefield ever had.

ʃi nɑɾəd tə wʌn ə hɝ ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, keɪlə bɛnt, hu pæs baɪ ðə bæk ɹoʊ ʌv ðə meɪkʃɪf θiəɾɝ ən səluɾəd.

She nodded to one of her Guardswomen, Kaila Bent, who passed by the back row of the makeshift theater and saluted.

"wɛl?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt, stɛpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ tə spik wɪð keɪlə. "nʌθɪŋ tə ɹipɔɹt," keɪlə sɛd. "ɔl ɪz wɛl." ʃi wɑz ə læŋki faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən, ən hæd teɪkən vɛɹi izəli tə wɛɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹaʊzɝz ən koʊɾ ʌv ə ɡɑɹdzwʊmən. "ɔɹəɡən, ɔl ɪz əz wɛl əz ɪt kəd bi waɪl hævɪŋ tə sʌfɝ θɹu ðə dɛθ ə pɹɪnsɛs wælɪʃən'.'

"Well?" Birgitte asked, stepping around the corner to speak with Kaila. "Nothing to report," Kaila said. "All is well." She was a lanky fire-haired woman, and had taken very easily to wearing the trousers and coat of a Guardswoman. "Or, all is as well as it could be while having to suffer through The Death of Princess Walishen'.'

stɑp kəmpleɪnɪŋ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, səpɹɛsɪŋ ə wɪns əz ðə divə - soʊ ðə pleɪɝz kɔld əɹ -  bɪɡæn ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ʃɹɪl ɑɹiə - soʊ ðeɪ kɔld ə sɔŋ baɪ jɝsɛlf. waɪ dɪd ðə pleɪɝz nid soʊ mɛni nu neɪmz fəɹ θɪŋz? "ju kəd bi aʊt pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn."

Stop complaining," Birgitte said, suppressing a wince as the diva - so the players called her -  began a particularly shrill aria - so they called a song by yourself. Why did the players need so many new names for things? "You could be out patrolling in the rain."

"aɪ kʊd?" keɪlə æskt, saʊndɪŋ iɡɝ. "waɪ dɪdn jə seɪ soʊ sunɝ? meɪbi əl ɡɛt stʃɹʌk baɪ laɪtnɪŋ. ðət maɪt bi pɹɛfɝəbəl." bɝdʒɪt snɔɹɾɪd. "ɡɛt bæk tə jəɹ ɹaʊnz." keɪlə səluɾəd ən lɛft. bɝdʒɪt tun bæk ɪndə ðə θiəɾɝ, linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə pɪlɝ. pɝhæps ʃi ʃʊɾə bɹɔt səm wæks tə stʌf ɪn əɹ ɪɹz. ʃi ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɾ ɪleɪn. ðə kwin sæt wɪð ə kɑm dɪminɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə pleɪ. ət taɪmz, bɝdʒɪt fɛl mɔɹ laɪk ə nɝsmeɪd ðən ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd. haʊ dɪd jə pɹətɛkt ə wʊmən u simd, ət taɪmz, soʊ dɪtɝ- maɪn tə si hɝsɛlf dɛd?

"I could?" Kaila asked, sounding eager. "Why didn't you say so sooner? Maybe I'll get struck by lightning. That might be preferable." Birgitte snorted. "Get back to your rounds." Kaila saluted and left. Birgitte tuned back into the theater, leaning against the pillar. Perhaps she should have brought some wax to stuff in her ears. She glanced over at Elayne. The Queen sat with a calm demeanor, watching the play. At times, Birgitte felt more like a nursemaid than a bodyguard. How did you protect a woman who seemed, at times, so deter- mined to see herself dead?

ən jɛt, ɪleɪn wɑz ɔlsoʊ soʊ vɛɹi keɪpəbəl. laɪk tənaɪt; ʃid sʌmhaʊ kənvɪnst əɹ moʊs bɪɾɝ ɹaɪvəl tə ətɛn ðɪs pleɪ. ðət wɑz ɛlɹin sɪt-tɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪn ði istɝn ɹoʊ; ðə wʊmənz læs pɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə pæləs hæd bɪn soʊ bɪɾɝ ðət bɝdʒɪt hædn ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə ɹɪtɝn ənlɛs ʃi wɑz ɪn tʃeɪnz.

And yet, Elayne was also so very capable. Like tonight; she'd somehow convinced her most bitter rival to attend this play. That was Ellorien sit-ting over in the eastern row; the woman's last parting from the palace had been so bitter that Birgitte hadn't expected her to return unless she was in chains.

jɛt hɪɹ ʃi wɑz. ɪt wɪspɝɾ ʌv ə pəlɪɾəkəl mənuvɝ baɪ ɪleɪn ðət wɑz θɝtin stɛps mɔɹ sʌɾəl ðən bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ə maɪn fɔɹ.

Yet here she was. It whispered of a political maneuver by Elayne that was thirteen steps more subtle than Birgitte had a mind for.

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ɪleɪn wɑz ə kwin. vɑlətɪləɾi ən ɔl. ʃid bi ɡʊd fəɹ ændɝ. əsumɪŋ bɝdʒɪt kəd kip ðət ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd hɛd fɹəm biɪŋ lɑpt ɔf ɪts nɛk.

She shook her head. Elayne was a queen. Volatility and all. She'd be good for Andor. Assuming Birgitte could keep that golden-haired head from being lopped off its neck.

æftɝ səm taɪm sʌfɝɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪŋɪŋ, keɪlə əpɹoʊtʃt əɡɛn. bɝdʒɪt stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, kjʊɹiəs ət ðə wʊmənz kwɪk peɪs. "wʌt?" ʃi æskt kwaɪətli.

After some time suffering through the singing, Kaila approached again. Birgitte stood up straight, curious at the woman's quick pace. "What?" she asked quietly.

"ju lʊk bɔɹd," keɪlə wɪspɝd, "soʊ aɪ θɔɾ aɪd bɹɪŋ ðɪs tə ju. dɪstɝbəns ət ðə plʌm ɡeɪt." ðət wɑz ðə saʊθistɝn ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə pæləs ɡɹaʊnz. "sʌmwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə snik θɹu."

"You looked bored," Kaila whispered, "so I thought I'd bring this to you. Disturbance at the Plum Gate." That was the southeastern entrance to the palace grounds. "Someone tried to sneak through."

"ənʌðɝ bɛɡɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ skɹæps? əɹ ə spaɪ fəɹ wʌn ə ðə lɔɹɾəlɪŋz, hoʊpɪŋ tə lɪsən ɪn?"

"Another beggar looking for scraps? Or a spy for one of the lordlings, hoping to listen in?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," keɪlə sɛd. "aɪ hɝd ðə nuz θɝdhæn fɹəm kɑlɪsən əz wi pæst ɑn pətʃɹoʊl. hi sɛd ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn əv ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ ɪn kʌstəɾi ət ðə ɡeɪt."

"I don't know," Kaila said. "I heard the news thirdhand from Calison as we passed on patrol. He said the Guardsmen have the intruder in custody at the gate."

bɝdʒɪt ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd. ɪt lʊk laɪk ənʌðɝ soʊloʊ wɑz əbaʊt tə bɪɡɪn. "ju hæv kəmæn hɪɹ; hoʊl ðɪs poʊst ən teɪk ɹɪpɔɹts. əl ɡoʊ stʃɹɛtʃ maɪ lɛɡz ən tʃɛk ɑn ðɪs dɪstɝbəns."

Birgitte glanced to the side. It looked like another solo was about to begin. "You have command here; hold this post and take reports. I'll go stretch my legs and check on this disturbance."

"bɹɪŋ mi səm wæks fəɹ maɪ ɪɹz wən jə kʌm bæk, wəd ju?"

"Bring me some wax for my ears when you come back, would you?"

bɝdʒɪt tʃʌkəld, livɪŋ ðə θiəɾɝ ən stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ə waɪt-ænd-ɹɛd pæləs hɔlweɪ. ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ən mɛn wɪð ɛkstʃɹə baʊz ət ðə hɔlweɪz, bɝdʒɪt hɝsɛlf kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹd, fəɹ ən əsæsəneɪʃən ətɛmpt wəd moʊs laɪkli tɝn tə kloʊz-kɔɹɾɝz faɪɾɪŋ.

Birgitte chuckled, leaving the theater and stepping into a white-and-red palace hallway. Though she had Guardswomen and men with extra bows at the hallways, Birgitte herself carried a sword, for an assassination attempt would most likely turn to close-quarters fighting.

bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑɾəd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ, ɡlænsɪŋ aʊɾ ə wɪndoʊ wən ʃi pæst. ðə skaɪ likt ə stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ dʒɹɪzəl. ʌɾɝli dʒɹɪɹi. ɡeɪɾəl wʊɾə laɪk ðɪs wɛðɝ. hi lʌv ðə ɹeɪn. ɑn əkeɪʒən, ʃid dʒoʊk ðət dʒɹɪzəl suɾəd ɪz feɪs bɛɾɝ, meɪkɪŋ ɪm lɛs laɪkli tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən.

Birgitte trotted down the hallway, glancing out a window when she passed. The sky leaked a strengthening drizzle. Utterly dreary. Gaidal would have liked this weather. He loved the rain. On occasion, she'd joked that drizzle suited his face better, making him less likely to frighten children.

laɪt, bʌt ʃi mɪs ðət mæn.

Light, but she missed that man.

ðə moʊs dɝɛkt ɹut tə ðə plʌm ɡeɪt tʊk əɹ θɹu ðə sɝvəns kɔɹɾɝz. ɪn mɛni pæləsəz, ðɪs wʊɾə mɛn ɛntɝɪŋ ə sɛkʃən ə ðə bɪldɪŋ ðət wɑz mɔɹ dʒɹæb, mɛn fəɹ lɛs ɪmpɔɹɾənt pipəl. bʌt ðɪs bɪldɪŋ hæd bɪn oʊɡiɝ bɪlt, ən ðeɪ hæd pɝtɪkjəlɝ vjuz əbaʊt sətʃ θɪŋz. ðə mɑɹbəl stoʊnwɝk hɪɹ wɑz əz ɡɹæn əz ɪt wɑz ɛlswɛɹ, wɪð taɪl moʊzeɪɪks ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪt. ðə ɹumz, waɪl smɔl baɪ ɹɔɪəl stændɝdz, wɝ itʃ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ən ɪntaɪɝ fæmli. bɝdʒɪt dʒɛnɝəli pɹəfɝd tə teɪk əɹ milz ɪn ðə sɝvəns' lɑɹdʒ, oʊpən daɪnɪŋ hɔl. fɔɹ sɛpɹət hɑɹθs kɹækəl hɪɹ ɪn dɪfaɪəns ə ðə dʒɹɪɹi naɪt, ən ɔf-duɾi sɝvəns ən ɡɑɹdz læft ən tʃæɾəd. səm sɛd jə kəd dʒʌdʒ ə mɑnɑɹk baɪ ðə weɪ hi tʃɹiɾəd ðoʊz u sɝv hɪm. ɪf ðət wɝ ðə keɪs, ðən ði ændɔɝən pæləs hæd bɪn dɪzaɪn ɪn ə weɪ tə ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə bɛst ɪn ɪts kwinz.

The most direct route to the Plum Gate took her through the servants quarters. In many palaces, this would have meant entering a section of the building that was more drab, meant for less important people. But this building had been Ogier built, and they had particular views about such things. The marble stonework here was as grand as it was elsewhere, with tiled mosaics of red and white. The rooms, while small by royal standards, were each large enough to hold an entire family. Birgitte generally preferred to take her meals in the servants' large, open dining hall. Four separate hearths crackled here in defiance of the dreary night, and off-duty servants and Guards laughed and chatted. Some said you could judge a monarch by the way he treated those who served him. If that were the case, then the Andoran palace had been designed in a way to encourage the best in its queens.

bɝdʒɪt ɹɪlʌktənli pæs baɪ ði ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ sɛns ə fuɾ ən ɪnstɛd pʊʃɪŋ əɹ weɪ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə koʊl sʌmɝ stɔɹm. ðə tʃɪl wɑzn baɪɾɪŋ. dʒʌst ənkʌmftəɹbəl. ʃi pʊld ʌp ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk ən kɹɔs ðə slɪk peɪvɪŋ daʊn tə ðə plʌm ɡeɪt. ðə ɡɑthaʊs wɑz əlaɪt wɪð ən ɔɹənʒ ɡloʊ, ən ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɑn wɑtʃ stʊɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn wɛt kloʊks, hælbɝdz hɛl tə ðə saɪd.

Birgitte reluctantly passed by the inviting scents of food and instead pushing her way out into the cold summer storm. The chill wasn't biting. Just uncomfortable. She pulled up the hood of her cloak and crossed the slick paving down to the Plum Gate. The gatehouse was alight with an orange glow, and the Guardsmen on watch stood outside in wet cloaks, halberds held to the side.

bɝdʒɪt mɑɹtʃt ʌp tə ðə ɡɑthaʊs, wɔɾɝ dʒɹɪpɪŋ fɹəm ðə lɪp ə hɝ hʊd, ðən paʊndɪɾ ɑn ðə θɪk oʊk dɔɹ. ɪɾ oʊpənd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə bɔld-hɛɾəd, mʌstæʃt feɪs ə ɹɪnəl məsɝ, sɑɹdʒən ɑn duɾi. ə staʊt mæn, hi hæd waɪd hænz ən ə kɑm tɛmpɹəmənt. ʃi ɔlweɪz θɔɾ i ʃəd bi ɪn ə ʃɑp sʌmwɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ʃuz, bʌt ðə ɡɑɹd tʊk ɔl taɪps, ən dɪpɛndəbɪlɪɾi wɑz ɔfən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən skɪl wɪð ðə sɔɹd.

Birgitte marched up to the gatehouse, water dripping from the lip of her hood, then pounded on the thick oak door. It opened, revealing the bald-headed, mustached face of Renald Macer, sergeant on duty. A stout man, he had wide hands and a calm temperament. She always thought he should be in a shop somewhere making shoes, but the Guard took all types, and dependability was often more important than skill with the sword.

"kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl!" hi ɪkskleɪmd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?"

"Captain-General!" he exclaimed. "What are you doing here?"

"ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹeɪn ɑn," ʃi snæpt.

"Getting rained on," she snapped.

"oʊ, maɪ!" hi stɛp bæk, meɪkɪŋ weɪ fəɹ əɹ tə ɛntɝ ðə ɡɑthaʊs. ɪt hæɾ ə sɪŋɡəl kɹaʊɾəd ɹum. ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɑn stɔɹm ʃɪft -  minɪŋ twaɪs əz mɛni mɛn wəd wɝk ðə ɡeɪɾ əz juʒəwəl, bʌt ðeɪ wəɾ oʊnli hæv tə stæn aʊtsaɪɾ ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ɹoʊteɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə mɛn wɔɹmɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡɑthaʊs.

"Oh, my!" He stepped back, making way for her to enter the gatehouse. It had a single crowded room. The soldiers were on storm shift -  meaning twice as many men would work the gate as usual, but they would only have to stand outside an hour before rotating with the men warming inside the gatehouse.

θɹi ɡɑɹdzmɪn sæɾ əɾ ə teɪbəl, θɹoʊɪŋ daɪs ɪndə ə dɪsɪŋ bɑks waɪl ən oʊpən-fɹʌntɪɾ aɪɝn stoʊv kənsum lɔɡz ən wɔɹm ti. dɪsɪŋ wɪð ðə tʊɹ soʊlʒɝz wɑz ə wɪɹi mæn wɪð ə blæk skɑɹf ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðə bɑɾəm ə hɪz feɪs. hɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz skɹʌfi, hɪz hɛd tɑp baɪ ə mɑp ʌv wɛt bɹaʊn hɛɹ kɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz. bɹaʊn aɪz ɡlænst ət bɝdʒɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə ðə skɑɹf, ən ðə mæn sæŋk daʊn ə lɪɾəl ɪn ɪz sit.

Three Guardsmen sat at a table, throwing dice into a dicing box while an open-fronted iron stove consumed logs and warmed tea. Dicing with the tour soldiers was a wiry man with a black scarf wrapped around the bottom of his face. His clothing was scruffy, his head topped by a mop of wet brown hair kicking out in all directions. Brown eyes glanced at Birgitte over the top of the scarf, and the man sank down a little in his seat.

bɝdʒɪt tʊk ɔf əɹ kloʊk ən ʃʊk ɪt fɹi ʌv ɹeɪnwɔɾɝ. "ðɪs ɪz jəɹ ɪntʃɹuɾɝ, aɪ əsum?"

Birgitte took off her cloak and shook it free of rainwater. "This is your intruder, I assume?"

"waɪ, jɛs," ðə sɑɹdʒən sɛd. "haʊ dɪd jə hɪɹ əbaʊt ðæt?"

"Why, yes," the sergeant said. "How did you hear about that?"

ʃi aɪd ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ. "hi tʃɹaɪd tə snik ɑntu ðə pæləs ɡɹaʊnz, ən naʊ jə ɹeɪ dɪsɪŋ wɪð hɪm?"

She eyed the intruder. "He tried to sneak onto the palace grounds, and now you re dicing with him?"

ðə sɑɹdʒən ən ði ʌðɝ mɛn lʊkt ʃipɪʃ. "wɛl, maɪ leɪɾi-"

The sergeant and the other men looked sheepish. "Well, my Lady-"

"ɪm noʊ leɪɾi." nɑt ðɪs taɪm ət list. "aɪ wɝk fəɹ ə lɪvɪŋ."

"I'm no lady." Not this time at least. "I work for a living."

"ɝ, jɛs," məsɝ kəntɪnjud. "wɛl, hi ɡeɪv ʌp ɪz sɔɹd ɹɛɾəli, ən i dʌzn sim ðət deɪnʒɝəs. dʒʌst ənʌðɝ bɛɡɝ wɑntɪŋ skɹæps fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz. ɹaɪt naɪs fɛloʊ. θɔt wid ɡɛɾ ɪm wɔɹm bɪfɔɹ sɛndɪŋ ɪm aʊɾ ɪndə ðət wɛðɝ əɡɛn."

"Er, yes," Macer continued. "Well, he gave up his sword readily, and he doesn't seem that dangerous. Just another beggar wanting scraps from the kitchens. Right nice fellow. Thought we'd get him warm before sending him out into that weather again."

"ə bɛɡɝ," ʃi sɛd. "wɪð ə sɔɹd?"

"A beggar," she said. "With a sword?"

sɑɹdʒən məsɝ skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd. "aɪ ɡɛs ðəɾ ɪz kaɪndə ɑd."

Sergeant Macer scratched his head. "I guess that is kind of odd."

"ju kəd tʃɑɹm ðə hɛlməɾ ɔf ə dʒɛnɝəl ɑn ə bæɾəlfild, kʊdn ju, mæt?" ʃi sɛd.

"You could charm the helmet off a general on a battlefield, couldn't you, Mat?" she said.

"mæt?" ðə mæn æskt ɪn ə fəmɪljɝ vɔɪs. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə min, maɪ ɡʊd wʊmən. maɪ neɪm ɪz ɡɝɑɹd, ə sɪmpəl bɛɡɝ u hæz ə kwaɪɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ pæst, ɪf jə kɛɹ tə lɪsən tə ɪt - "

"Mat?" the man asked in a familiar voice. "I don't know what you mean, my good woman. My name is Garard, a simple beggar who has a quite interesting past, if you care to listen to it - "

ʃi aɪɾ ɪm wɪð ə fɝm ɡeɪz.

She eyed him with a firm gaze.

"oʊ, blʌɾi æʃəz, bɝdʒɪt," hi kəmpleɪnd, teɪkɪŋ ɔf ðə skɑɹf "aɪ oʊnli wɑntəd tə ɡɛt wɔɹm fəɹ ə spɛl."

"Oh, bloody ashes, Birgitte," he complained, taking off the scarf "I only wanted to get warm for a spell."

"ænd wɪn ðə kɔɪn ɔf maɪ mɛn."

"And win the coin off my men."

"ə fɹɛnli ɡeɪm nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə mæn," mæt sɛd.

"A friendly game never hurt a man," Mat said.

"ənlɛs ɪt wɑz əɡɛns ju. lʊk, waɪ ɑɹ jə snikɪŋ ɪndə ðə pæləs?"

"Unless it was against you. Look, why are you sneaking into the palace?"

"ɪt tʊk tu mʌtʃ blʌɾi wɝk tə ɡɛɾ ɪn læs taɪm," mæt sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ. "θɔɾ aɪ maɪt pæs ðəɾ ʌp ðɪs taɪm."

"It took too much bloody work to get in last time," Mat said, sitting back in his chair. "Thought I might pass that up this time."

sɑɹdʒən məsɝ ɡlænst ət bɝdʒɪt. "ju noʊ ðɪs mæn?"

Sergeant Macer glanced at Birgitte. "You know this man?"

"ənfɔɹtʃənətli," ʃi sɛd. "ju kən ɹilis ɪm tə maɪ kʌstəɾi, sɑɹdʒənt. əl si ðət mæstɝ kɔθən ɪz pɹɑpɝli teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv."

"Unfortunately," she said. "You can release him to my custody, Sergeant. I'll see that Master Cauthon is properly taken care of."

"mæstɝ kɔθən?" wʌn ə ðə mɛn sɛd. "ju min ðə ɹeɪvən pɹɪns?"

"Master Cauthon?" one of the men said. "You mean the Raven Prince?"

"oʊ, fəɹ blʌɾi . . ." mæt sɛd, əz i stʊɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ɪz wɔkɪŋ stæf. "θæŋks," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli tə bɝdʒɪt, θɹoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪz koʊt.

"Oh, for bloody . . ." Mat said, as he stood and picked up his walking staff. "Thanks," he said dryly to Birgitte, throwing on his coat.

ʃi pʊɾ əɹ kloʊk bæk ɑn, ðən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ əz wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz hændəd mæt ɪz sɔɹd, bɛl stɪl ətætʃt. sɪns wən hæd mæt kæɹiɾ ə ʃɔɹts wɝd? pɹɑbli ə dəkɔɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf.

She put her cloak back on, then pushed open the door as one of the Guards handed Mat his sword, belt still attached. Since when had Mat carried a shorts word? Probably a decoy away from the quarterstaff.

ðə tu stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹeɪn əz mæt taɪɾ ɑn ðə bɛlt. "ɹeɪvən pɹɪns?" ʃi æskt.

The two stepped out into the rain as Mat tied on the belt. "Raven Prince?" she asked.

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"I don't want to talk about it."

"waɪ nɑt?"

"Why not?"

"bɪkɔz aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ tu blʌɾi feɪməs fəɹ maɪ oʊn ɡʊd, ðæts waɪ.

"Because I'm getting too bloody famous for my own good, that's why.

"weɪɾ əntɪl ɪt tʃɹæks jə əkɹɔs dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz," ʃi sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp ət ðə skaɪ, blɪŋkɪŋ əz ə ɹeɪndʒɹɑp hɪɾ əɹ skwɛɹ ɪn ði aɪ.

"Wait until it tracks you across generations," she said, glancing up at the sky, blinking as a raindrop hit her square in the eye.

"kʌm ɑn, lɛts ɡoʊ ɡɹæb ə dʒɹɪŋk," mæt sɛd, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪt.

"Come on, let's go grab a drink," Mat said, walking toward the gate.

"weɪt," ʃi sɛd. "doʊn jə wɑnə ɡoʊ si ɪleɪn?"

"Wait," she said. "Don't you want to go see Elayne?"

"ɪleɪn?" mæt sɛd. "blʌɾ ən æʃəz, bɝdʒɪt, aɪm hɪɹ tə tɔk tə ju. waɪ dʒju θɪŋk aɪ lɛt ðoʊz ɡɑɹdz kætʃ mi? jə wɑn ə dʒɹɪŋk əɹ nɑt?"

"Elayne?" Mat said. "Blood and ashes, Birgitte, I'm here to talk to you. Why do you think I let those Guards catch me? You want a drink or not?"

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃɹʌɡd. baɪ pʊɾɪŋ keɪlə ɑn duɾi ɪn əɹ pleɪs, bɝdʒɪt hæɾ əfɪʃəli ɡɔn ɑn bɹeɪk. ʃi nu ə fɛɹli disən tævɝn oʊnli tu stʃɹits fɹəm ðə pæləs.

She hesitated, then shrugged. By putting Kaila on duty in her place, Birgitte had officially gone on break. She knew a fairly decent tavern only two streets from the Palace.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," ʃi sɛd, weɪvɪŋ tə ðə ɡɑɹdz ən liɾɪŋ mæt ɑntu ðə ɹeɪni stʃɹit. "bʌɾ əl nid tə hæv mɪlk əɹ ti ɪnstɛɾ ʌv eɪl. wi ɑɹənt ʃʊɹ ɪf əɹ wɔɹɾɝ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wəd bi bæd fəɹ ðə beɪbiz əɹ nɑt." ʃi smaɪld, θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ə dʒɹʌŋk ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔk tə hɝ ælaɪz æftɝ ðə pleɪ. "ðoʊ ɪf aɪ meɪk əɹ tɪpsi, ɪt maɪt bi ɡʊd ɹivɛnʒ fəɹ səm ə ðə θɪŋz ʃiz dʌn tə mi."

"All right," she said, waving to the Guards and leading Mat onto the rainy street. "But I'll need to have milk or tea instead of ale. We aren't sure if her Warder drinking would be bad for the babies or not." She smiled, thinking of a drunk Elayne trying to talk to her allies after the play. "Though if I make her tipsy, it might be good revenge for some of the things she's done to me."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ jə lɛɾ əɹ bɑn jə ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs," mæt sɛd. ðə stʃɹit wɑz nɪɹli ɛmpti ɝaʊn ðɛm, ðoʊ ðə tævɝn ʌp əhɛd lʊkt ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ, ɪts jɛloʊ laɪt spɪlɪŋ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit.

"I don't know why you let her bond you in the first place," Mat said. The street was nearly empty around them, though the tavern up ahead looked inviting, its yellow light spilling into the street.

"aɪ dɪdn əv ə seɪ ɪn ðə mæɾɝ," ʃi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt. dɪd jə ɹɪli snik ɪndə ðə pæləs tə mit wɪð mi?"

"I didn't have a say in the matter," she said. "But I don't regret it. Did you really sneak into the palace to meet with me?"

mæt ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ hæv səm kwɛstʃənz."

Mat shrugged. "I have some questions."

"əbaʊt wʌt?"

"About what?"

hi ɹipleɪs ðət ɹɪdɪkjələs skɑɹf, wɪtʃ ʃi noʊɾəst hæɾ ə ɹɪp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl. "ju noʊ," hi sɛd.

He replaced that ridiculous scarf, which she noticed had a rip in the middle. "You know," he said.

"θɪŋz."

"Things."

mæt wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu nu hu ʃi ɹɪli wɑz. hi kʊdn min. . . . "noʊ," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ, "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt."

Mat was one of the few who knew who she really was. He couldn't mean. . . . "No," she said, turning, "I don't want to talk about it."

"blʌɾi æʃəz, bɝdʒɪt! aɪ nid jəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. kʌm ɑn, fəɹ ən oʊl fɹɛnd."

"Bloody ashes, Birgitte! I need your information. Come on, for an old friend."

"wi əɡɹid tə kip itʃ ʌðɝz sikɹəts."

"We agreed to keep each other's secrets."

"æn aɪm nɑɾ aʊt blæbɪŋ jʊɹz," mæt sɛd kwɪkli. "bʌt, si, ðɛɹz ðɪs ɪʃu."

"And I'm not out blabbing yours," Mat said quickly. "But, see, there's this issue."

"wʌɾ ɪʃu?" "ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ."

"What issue?" "The Tower of Ghenjei."

ðæts nɑɾ ən ɪʃu," ʃi sɛd. "ju steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɪt." "aɪ kænt."

That's not an issue," she said. "You stay away from it." "I can't."

ʌv kɔɹs jə kæn. ɪts ə fleɪmɪŋ bɪldɪŋ, mæt. ɪt kæn ɪɡzækli tʃeɪs jə daʊn."

Of course you can. It's a flaming building, Mat. It can't exactly chase you down."

vɛɹi əmjuzɪŋ. lʊk, wɪl jə ət lis hɪɹ mi aʊt, oʊvɝ ə mʌɡ? ʌv, ɝ, mɪlk. əl baɪ."

Very amusing. Look, will you at least hear me out, over a mug? Of, er, milk. I'll buy."

ʃi stɑp fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ðən ʃi saɪd. "blʌɾi ɹaɪt, jəl baɪ,"

She stopped for a moment. Then she sighed. "Bloody right, you'll buy,"

ʃi mʌɾɝd, weɪvɪŋ ɪm ɔnwɝd. ðeɪ ɛntɝd ði ɪn, noʊn əz ðə ɡɹæn haɪk, wɪtʃ wɑz kɹaʊɾəd bɪɑn juʒəwəl kəz ə ðə ɹeɪn. ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ə fɹɛn ə bɝdʒɪts, haʊɛvɝ, ən i hæd ðə baʊnsɝ tɔs aʊɾ ə dʒɹʌŋkɝd slipɪŋ ɪn wʌn ə ðə buθs tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ hɝ.

she muttered, waving him onward. They entered the inn, known as The Grand Hike, which was crowded beyond usual because of the rain. The innkeeper was a friend of Birgitte's, however, and he had the bouncer toss out a drunkard sleeping in one of the booths to make room for her.

ʃi tɔst ɪm ə kɔɪn ɪn θæŋks, ən i nɑɾəd ɪz ʌɡli hɛd tə hɝ - hi wɑz mɪsɪŋ sɛvɹəl tiθ, wʌn aɪ, ən moʊst ə hɪz hɛɹ. bɛst- lʊkɪŋ mæn ɪn ðə pleɪs. bɝdʒɪt hɛld ʌp tu fɪŋɡɝz tə ɔɹɾɝ dʒɹɪŋks - hi nu ðət ʃi tʊk mɪlk ðiz deɪz - ən ʃi weɪv mæt tə ðə buθ.

She tossed him a coin in thanks, and he nodded his ugly head to her - he was missing several teeth, one eye, and most of his hair. Best- looking man in the place. Birgitte held up two fingers to order drinks - he knew that she took milk these days - and she waved Mat to the booth.

"wʌn doʊn ɹaɪtli θɪŋk aɪv ɛvɝ sin ən ʌɡliɝ mæn ðən ðəɾ ɪnkipɝ," mæt sɛɾ əz ðeɪ sæt.

"1 don't rightly think I've ever seen an uglier man than that innkeeper," Mat said as they sat.

"ju hævən bɪn əlaɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf," ʃi sɛd, linɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl ən pʊɾɪŋ əɹ buɾɪd fiɾ ʌp ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌst ɹum ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə də soʊ, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ ə ðə buθ lɛŋθwaɪz. "ɪf oʊl snɝt wɝ ə fju jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ, ən ɪf sʌmwʌn θɔt tə bɹeɪk ɪz noʊz ɪn ə fju pleɪsəz, aɪ maɪt kənsɪɾɝ hɪm. hiz ɡɑɾ ə faɪn tʃɛst, naɪs ən fʊl ə kɝli hɛɹ tə ɡɛt jəɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn."

"You haven't been alive long enough," she said, leaning back against the wall and putting her booted feet up on the table. There was just room enough for her to do so, sitting on the bench of the booth lengthwise. "If Old Snert were a few years younger, and if someone thought to break his nose in a few places, I might consider him. He's got a fine chest, nice and full of curly hair to get your fingers in."

mæt ɡɹɪnd. "hæv aɪ ɛvɝ mɛnʃən haʊ ɑɾ ɪts tə ɡoʊ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɪð ə wʊmən u tɔks əbaʊt mɛn laɪk ðæt?"

Mat grinned. "Have I ever mentioned how odd it is to go drinking with a woman who talks about men like that?"

ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. waɪ ɪn ðə neɪm ə nɔɹməɾ ɛs ɪɹz ɑɹ jə wɑntɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ðɛɹ?"

She shrugged. "Ghenjei. Why in the name of Normad s Ears are you wanting to go there?"

"huz ɪɹz?" mæt æskt.

"Whose ears?" Mat asked.

"ænsɝ mi."

"Answer me."

mæt saɪd, ðən æbsənli æksɛptɪɾ ɪz mʌɡ əz ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪt. ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli, hi dɪdn slæp əɹ bæksaɪd, ðoʊ hi dɪd ɡɪv əɹ ə ɡʊd lɪɹ əz ʃi wɔkt əweɪ. "ðə blʌɾi sneɪks ən fɑksəz əv ə fɹɛn ə maɪn," hi sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz skɑɹf ən teɪkɪŋ ə pʊl ɑn ɪz dʒɹɪŋk.

Mat sighed, then absently accepted his mug as the serving girl delivered it. Uncharacteristically, he didn't slap her backside, though he did give her a good leer as she walked away. "The bloody snakes and foxes have a friend of mine," he said, lowering his scarf and taking a pull on his drink.

"liv hɪm. jə kæn seɪv hɪm, mæt. ɪf i wɑz fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ ɪndə ðɛɹ ɹɛlm, hi dɪzɝvz wʌɾ i ɡɑt."

"Leave him. You can't save him, Mat. If he was foolish enough to go into their realm, he deserves what he got."

"ɪts ə wʊmən," mæt sɛd.

"It's a woman," Mat said.

ɑ. bɝdʒɪt θɔt. blʌɾi ful. hɪɹoʊɪk, bʌt stɪl ə ful.

Ah. Birgitte thought. Bloody fool. Heroic, but still a fool.

"aɪ kæn liv hɝ," mæt kəntɪnjud. "aɪ oʊ hɝ. bɪsaɪdz, ə ɡʊd fɹɛn ə maɪn ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn wɛðɝ aɪ wɑn ɪm tə əɹ nɑt. aɪ hæv tə hɛlp."

"I can't leave her," Mat continued. "I owe her. Besides, a good friend of mine is going in whether I want him to or not. I have to help."

"ðɛn ðəl əv ɔl θɹi ʌv ju," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "lʊk, ɪf jə ɡoʊ ɪn θɹu ðə pɔɹɾəlz, ðən jəɹ lɑkt ɪndə ðə tʃɹiɾiz. ðeɪ pɹətɛk jə tə ən ɪkstɛnt, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ ɹistʃɹɪk ju. jəl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɛniwɛɹ jusfəl æftɝ ɛntɝɪŋ baɪ wʌn ə ði ɑɹtʃweɪz."

"Then they'll have all three of you," Birgitte said. "Look, if you go in through the portals, then you're locked into the treaties. They protect you to an extent, but they also restrict you. You'll never get anywhere useful after entering by one of the archways."

"æn ɪf jə ɡoʊ ɪn ði ʌðɝ weɪ?" mæt æskt. "ju toʊld oʊlvɝ haʊ tə oʊpən ðə taʊɝ."

"And if you go in the other way?" Mat asked. "You told Olver how to open the Tower."

"bɪkɔz aɪ wɑz tɛlɪŋ ɪm ə bɛdtaɪm stɔɹi! laɪt, aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt wʌn ə jə sæp-fɔɹ-bɹeɪnz wəɾ æktʃəli  tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn!"

"Because I was telling him a bedtime story! Light, I never thought one of you sap-for-brains would actually try to get in!"

"bʌɾ ɪf wi ɡoʊ ɪn ðət weɪ, kən wi faɪn hɝ?"

"But if we go in that way, can we find her?"

"maɪeɪb," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, "bʌt jə woʊnt. ðə tʃɹiɾiz woʊn bi ɪn ɪfɛkt, soʊ ði ɛln ən ɛlfɪn kən dʒɹɔ blʌd. nɔɹməli, jə oʊnli hæv tə wɝi əbaʊt tʃɹɪks wɪð pɪts əɹ ɹoʊps, sɪns ðeɪ kænt. . . ." ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɪm. "haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛt hæŋd, ɛniweɪ?"

"Mayaybe," Birgitte said, "but you won't. The treaties won't be in effect, so the Aelnnn and Eelfinn can draw blood. Normally, you only have to worry about tricks with pits or ropes, since they can't. . . ." She trailed off, glancing at him. "How did you get hanged, anyway?"
