hi flʌʃt, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɪndə hɪz dʒɹɪŋk. "ðeɪ ʃəd poʊst ə fleɪmɪŋ ɛkspləneɪʃən ɑn ðoʊz ɑɹtʃweɪz. 'stɛp θɹu hɪɹ ən ðeɪ kən blʌɾi hæŋ ju-.æn ðeɪ wɪl. ɪɾiət.'"

He flushed, looking down into his drink. "They should post a flaming explanation on those archways. 'Step through here and they can bloody hang you-.And they will. Idiot.'"

bɝdʒɪt snɔɹɾɪd. ðeɪd tɔkt əbaʊt ðə mɛmɹiz i hæd. ʃi ʃʊɾə pʊɾ ɪt təɡɛðɝ. "ɪf jə ɡoʊ ɪn ði ʌðɝ weɪ, ðəl pɹɑbli tʃɹaɪ ðəɾ əz wɛl. ʃɛɾɪŋ blʌɾ ɪn ðɛɹ kɪŋdəm kən əv stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪfɛks. ðəl tʃɹaɪ tə bɹeɪk jəɹ boʊnz wɪð ə fɔl əɹ dʒɹʌɡ jə tə slip. ən ðəl wɪn, mæt. ɪts ðɛɹ wɝld."

Birgitte snorted. They'd talked about the memories he had. She should have put it together. "If you go in the other way, they'll probably try that as well. Shedding blood in their kingdom can have strange effects. They'll try to break your bones with a fall or drug you to sleep. And they will win, Mat. It's their world."

"æn ɪf wi tʃit?" mæt æskt. "aɪɝn, mjuzɪk, faɪɝ."

"And if we cheat?" Mat asked. "Iron, music, fire."

"ðæts nɑt tʃiɾɪŋ. ðæts biɪŋ smɑɹt. ɛvɹiwʌn wɪð hæf ə wɪɾ u ɛntɝz θɹu ðə taʊɝ kæɹiz ðoʊz θɪŋz. bʌɾ oʊnli wʌn aʊɾ ʌv ə θaʊzən meɪks ɪt bæk aʊt, mæt."

"That's not cheating. That's being smart. Everyone with half a wit who enters through the tower carries those things. But only one out of a thousand makes it back out, Mat."

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən fɪʃt ə smɔl hændfʊl ə kɔɪnz aʊɾ ə hɪz pɑkət. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ði ɑdz ɑɹ ðəɾ ɪf aɪ tɔs ðiz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ðəl ɔl kʌm ʌp hɛdz? wʌn ɪn ə θaʊzənd?"

He hesitated, then fished a small handful of coins out of his pocket. "What do you think the odds are that if I toss these into the air, they will all come up heads? One in a thousand?"

"mæt . . ."

"Mat . . ."

hi tɔst əm əbʌv ðə teɪbəl. ðeɪ keɪm daʊn ɪn ə spɹeɪ, hɪɾɪŋ ðə teɪbəltɑp. nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn ə ðɛm baʊnst əɹ ɹoʊl fɹəm ðə teɪbəl ɑntu ðə flɔɹ.

He tossed them above the table. They came down in a spray, hitting the tabletop. Not a single one of them bounced or rolled from the table onto the floor.

mæt dɪdn lʊk daʊn ət ðə kɔɪnz. hi mɛɾ əɹ aɪz əz ðeɪ ɔl ɹoʊld ən vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd tə ə stɑp. ʃi ɡlænst ət ðɛm. tu dʌzən kɔɪnz. itʃ hæd lændəd feɪs ʌp.

Mat didn't look down at the coins. He met her eyes as they all rolled and vibrated to a stop. She glanced at them. Two dozen coins. Each had landed face up.

"wʌn ɪn ə θaʊzən ɪz ɡʊɾ ɑdz," hi sɛd. "fɔɹ mi."

"One in a thousand is good odds," he said. "For me."

"blʌɾi æʃəz. jəɹ əz bæɾ əz ɪleɪn! doʊn jə si? ɔl ɪt teɪks ɪz wʌn ɹɔŋ θɹoʊ. ivən jə mɪs wʌns ɪn ə waɪl."

"Bloody ashes. You're as bad as Elayne! Don't you see? All it takes is one wrong throw. Even you miss once in a while."

"aɪl teɪk ðə tʃæns. bɝn mi, bɝdʒɪt, aɪ noʊ ɪts stupəd, bʌɾ aɪm du-ɪŋ ɪt. haʊ dʒju noʊ soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðə taʊɝ ɛniweɪ? juv bɪn ɪndə ɪt, hævən ju?"

"I'll take the chance. Burn me, Birgitte, I know it's stupid, but I'm do-ing it. How do you know so much about the Tower anyway? You've been into it, haven't you?"

"aɪ hæv," ʃi ədmɪɾəd.

"I have," she admitted.

mæt lʊk smʌɡ. "wɛl jə ɡɑt bæk aʊt! haʊd jə mænədʒ ɪt?"

Mat looked smug. "Well you got back out! How'd you manage it?"

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən faɪnəli tʊk ʌp əɹ mʌɡ ʌv mɪlk. "ðæt lɛdʒən dɪdn sɝvaɪv, aɪm əsumɪŋ?" "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪt," mæt sɛd. "aɪ wɛn ɪn tə æsk əm tə seɪv ðə laɪf ə maɪ lʌv," ʃi sɛd. "ɪt keɪm æftɝ ðə bæɾəl ə lɑpɔɪn hɪlz, wɛɹ wi lɛd ðə bjukənɝ ɹɪbɛljən.

She hesitated, then finally took up her mug of milk. "That legend didn't survive, I'm assuming?" "I don't know it," Mat said. "I went in to ask them to save the life of my love," she said. "It came after the battle of Lahpoint Hills, where we led the Buchaner rebellion.

ɡeɪɾəl wɑz wundəd hɔɹəbli; ə bloʊ tə ðə hɛd ðət meɪɾ ɪm əneɪbəl tə θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt. hi fɝɡɑɾ u aɪ wɑz, səm ə ðə taɪm. ɪt tɔɹ maɪ hɑɹt, soʊ aɪ tʊk ɪm tə ðə taʊɝ tə bi hild."

Gaidal was wounded horribly; a blow to the head that made him unable to think straight. He forgot who I was, some of the time. It tore my heart, so I took him to the Tower to be Healed."

"æn haʊd jə ɡɛɾ aʊt?" mæt æskt. "haʊd jə ful ðɛm?"

"And how'd you get out?" Mat asked. "How'd you fool them?"

"aɪ dɪdnt," bɝdʒɪt sɛd sɔfli. mæt fɹoʊz. "ði ɛlfɪn nɛvɝ hil hɪm," ʃi kəntɪnjud. "ðeɪ kɪld əs boʊθ aɪ dɪdn sɝvaɪv, mæt. ðəɾ ɪz ði ɛn ə ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ lɛdʒənd."

"I didn't," Birgitte said softly. Mat froze. "The Eelfinn never Healed him," she continued. "They killed us both I didn't survive, Mat. That is the end of that particular legend."

hi fɛl saɪlənt. "oʊ," hi faɪnəli sɛd. "wɛl, ðæts kaɪndə ə sæd stɔɹi, ðɛn."

He fell silent. "Oh," he finally said. "Well, that's kind of a sad story, then."

"ðeɪ kæn ɔl ɛn ɪn vɪktɝi. ɡeɪɾəl ən aɪ doʊn dil wɛl wɪð hæpi ɛndɪŋz ɛniweɪ. bɛɾɝ fəɹ əs tə bɝn aʊɾ ɪn ɡlɔɹi." ʃi ɡɹɪməst, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌn ɪnkɑɹneɪʃən wən ʃi ən i hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə ɡɹoʊ oʊl təɡɛðɝ, pisfəli. moʊs bɔɹɪŋ laɪf ʃiɾ ɛvɝ noʊn, ðoʊ ət ðə taɪm - ɪɡnɝən ə hɝ ɡɹændɝ pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn - ʃid bɪn hæpi wɪð ɪt.

"They can't all end in victory. Gaidal and I don't deal well with happy endings anyway. Better for us to burn out in glory." She grimaced, remembering one incarnation when she and he had been forced to grow old together, peacefully. Most boring life she'd ever known, though at the time - ignorant of her grander part in the Pattern - she'd been happy with it.

"wɛl ɪm stɪl ɡoʊɪŋ," mæt sɛd. ʃi saɪd. "aɪ kænt ɡoʊ wɪð ju, mæt. nɑɾ ən liv ɪleɪn. ʃiz ə dɛθ wɪʃ ðə saɪz ə jəɹ pɹaɪd, ən aɪ min tə si ʃi sɝvaɪvz."

"Well I'm still going," Mat said. She sighed. "I can't go with you, Mat. Not and leave Elayne. She has a death wish the size of your pride, and I mean to see she survives."

"aɪ doʊn ɪkspɛk jə tə ɡoʊ," mæt sɛd kwɪkli. "bɝn mi, ðæts nɑt wʌɾ aɪm æskɪŋ. ən . . ." hi fɹaʊnd. "ə dɛθ wʌt ðə saɪz ə maɪ wʌt!"

"I don't expect you to go," Mat said quickly. "Burn me, that's not what I'm asking. And . . ." He frowned. "A death what the size of my what!"

"nɛvɝ maɪnd," ʃi sɛd, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ əɹ mɪlk. ʃi hæɾ ə sɑf spɑt fəɹ mɪlk, ðoʊ ʃi dɪdn tɛl pipəl ʌv ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃid bi hæpi wən ʃi kəd dʒɹɪŋk əɡɛn; ʃi mɪst oʊl snɝts jisti dʒɹɪŋks. ʃi laɪkt ʌɡli bɪɹ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi laɪkt ʌɡli mɛn. "aɪ keɪm tə jə kəz aɪ nid hɛlp," mæt sɛd. "wʌt mɔɹ ɪz ðəɹ tə seɪ? jəɹ teɪkɪŋ aɪɝn, faɪɝ, ən mjuzɪk. aɪɝn wɪl hɝt ðɛm, wɔɹd ðɛm, ən hoʊl ðɛm. faɪɝ wɪl skɛɹ əm ən kɪl ðɛm. mjuzɪk wɪl ɛntʃɹɑns ðɛm. bʌt jəl faɪn ðət boʊθ faɪɝ ən mjuzɪk ɡɹoʊ lɛs ən lɛs ɪfɛktɪv ðə lɔŋɡɝ jə juz ðɛm.

"Never mind," she said, drinking her milk. She had a soft spot for milk, though she didn't tell people of it. Of course, she'd be happy when she could drink again; she missed Old Snert's yeasty drinks. She liked ugly beer as much as she liked ugly men. "I came to you because I need help," Mat said. "What more is there to say? You're taking iron, fire, and music. Iron will hurt them, ward them, and hold them. Fire will scare them and kill them. Music will entrance them. But you'll find that both fire and music grow less and less effective the longer you use them.

"ðə taʊɝ ɪzən ə pleɪs, ɪts ə pɔɹɾəl. ə kaɪndə ɡeɪt tə ðə kɹɔsɹoʊdz bɪtwin ðɛɹ ɹɛlmz.

"The tower isn't a place, it's a portal. A kind of gate to the crossroads between their realms.

jəl faɪn boʊθ ə ðɛm ðɛɹ, æɛlfɪn sneɪks ən ɛlfɪn fɑksəz. əsumɪŋ ðəɹ wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ kɝənli. ðeɪv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp."

You'll find both of them there, Aelfinn snakes and Eelfinn foxes. Assuming they're working together currently. They have a strange relationship."

"bʌt wʌt də ðeɪ wɑnt?" mæt æskt. "fɹʌm ʌs, aɪ min. waɪ də ðeɪ kɛɹ?"

"But what do they want?" Mat asked. "From us, I mean. Why do they care?"

"ɪmoʊʃən," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "ðæts waɪ ðeɪ bɪl pɔɹɾəlz ɪndə əɹ wɝld, ðæts waɪ ðeɪ ɪntaɪs əs ɪn. ðeɪ fiɾ ɔf wʌt wi fil. ðeɪ laɪk ɛɛs saʊθist-daɪ ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ, fəɹ səm ɹizən. pɝhæps ðoʊz wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ teɪs laɪk ə stʃɹɔŋ eɪl."

"Emotion," Birgitte said. "That's why they built portals into our world, that's why they entice us in. They feed off what we feel. They like Aes Se-dai in particular, for some reason. Perhaps those with the One Power taste like a strong ale."

mæt ʃɪvɝd vɪzəbli.

Mat shivered visibly.

"ði ɪnsaɪd wɪl bi kənfjuzɪŋ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "ɡɛɾɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ spəsɪfɪk ɪn ðəɹ ɪz dɪfəkəlt.

"The inside will be confusing," Birgitte said. "Getting anywhere specific in there is difficult.

ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn θɹu ðə taʊɝ ɪnstɛɾ ə ði ɑɹtʃweɪz pʊt mi ɪn deɪnʒɝ, bʌɾ aɪ nu ðəɾ ɪf aɪ kəd ɹitʃ ðət ɡɹæn hɔl, aɪd bi eɪbəl tə meɪk ə dil. jə doʊnt ɡɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ fɹi ɪf jə ɡoʊ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, baɪ ðə weɪ. ðəl æsk fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ dɪɹ tə ju.

Going in through the tower instead of the archways put me in danger, but I knew that if I could reach that grand hall, I'd be able to make a deal. You don't get anything free if you go in the tower, by the way. They'll ask for something, something dear to you.

"ɛniweɪ, aɪ fɪɡjɝɾ aʊɾ ə mɛθəd tə faɪn ðə ɡɹæn hɔl. aɪɝn dʌst, lɛf bɪhaɪn mi ɪn ði ɪntɝsɛkʃənz wɛɹ aɪd pæst soʊ ðəɾ aɪ nu wɪtʃ weɪz aɪd ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ. ðeɪ kʊdn tʌtʃ ɪt, jə si, ən ... ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ juv nɛvɝ hɝd ðɪs stɔɹi?"

"Anyway, I figured out a method to find the grand hall. Iron dust, left behind me in the intersections where I'd passed so that I knew which ways I'd gone before. They couldn't touch it, you see, and ... are you sure you've never heard this story?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪt juz tə bi pɑpjəlɝ ɝaʊn ðiz pɑɹts," ʃi sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ əɹ soʊ."

Mat shook his head. "It used to be popular around these parts," she said, frowning. "A hundred years ago or so."

"ju saʊn əfɛndəd."

"You sound offended."

"ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd stɔɹi," ʃi sɛd.

"It was a good story," she said.

"ɪf aɪ sɝvaɪv, əl əv θɔɹn kəmpoʊz ə blʌɾi bæləɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, bɝdʒɪt. tɛl mi əbaʊt ðə dʌst.

"If I survive, I'll have Thorn compose a bloody ballad about it, Birgitte. Tell me about the dust.

dɪd jəɹ plæn wɝk?" ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ stɪl ɡɑt lɔst. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðeɪ blu əweɪ ðə dʌst sʌmhaʊ, əɹ ɪf ðə pleɪs ɪz soʊ hjudʒ ðəɾ aɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪpiɾɪd maɪsɛlf. aɪ ɛndəɾ ʌp kɔɹnɝd, maɪ faɪɝ ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt, maɪ laɪɹ bɹoʊkən, maɪ bɑstʃɹɪŋ snæpt, ɡeɪɾəl ʌnkɑnʃəs bɪhaɪn mi. hi kəd wɔk səm ə ðə deɪz ɪn ðɛɹ, bʌt wɑz tu dɪzi ɑn ʌðɝz, soʊ aɪ pʊld ɪm ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ aɪd bɹɔt."

Did your plan work?" She shook her head. "I still got lost. I don't know if they blew away the dust somehow, or if the place is so huge that I never repeated myself. I ended up cornered, my fire going out, my lyre broken, my bowstring snapped, Gaidal unconscious behind me. He could walk some of the days in there, but was too dizzy on others, so I pulled him on the litter I'd brought."

"sʌm ə ðə deɪz?" mæt sɛd. "haʊ lɔŋ wɝ jə ɪn ðɛɹ?"

"Some of the days?" Mat said. "How long were you in there?"

"aɪ hæd pɹəvɪʒənz fəɹ tu mʌnθs," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "doʊnt noʊ haʊ lɔŋ wi læstəɾ æftɝ ðoʊz ɹæn aʊt."

"I had provisions for two months," Birgitte said, grimacing. "Don't know how long we lasted after those ran out."

"blʌɾi æʃəz!" mæt sɛd, ðən tʊk ə lɔŋ swɪɡ ʌv ɪz eɪl.

"Bloody ashes!" Mat said, then took a long swig of his ale.

"aɪ toʊl jə nɑt tə ɡoʊ ɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "əsumɪŋ jə də ɹitʃ jəɹ fɹɛnd, jəl nɛvɝ ɡɛt bæk aʊt. jə kən wɑndɝ fəɹ wiks ɪn ðət pleɪs ən nɛvɝ tɝn ɹaɪɾ əɹ lɛft, kip ɡoʊɪŋ stʃɹeɪt, pæsɪŋ hɔlweɪ æftɝ hɔlweɪ. ɔl ðə seɪm. ðə ɡɹæn hɔl kəd bi mɪnəts əweɪ, ɪf jə nu wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən tə teɪk. bʌt jəl kip mɪsɪŋ ɪt."

"I told you not to go in," Birgitte said. "Assuming you do reach your friend, you'll never get back out. You can wander for weeks in that place and never turn right or left, keep going straight, passing hallway after hallway. All the same. The grand hall could be minutes away, if you knew which direction to take. But you'll keep missing it."

mæt stɛɹɾ ɪndə hɪz mʌɡ, pɝhæps wɪʃɪŋ hiɾ ɔɹɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ poʊɾənt.

Mat stared into his mug, perhaps wishing he'd ordered something more potent.

"ju ɹikənsɪɾɝɪŋ?" ʃi æskt. ''noʊ," hi sɛd. "bʌt wən wi ɡɛɾ aʊt, mɔɪɹeɪn bɛɾɝ blʌɾi əpɹiʃieɪt ðɪs! tu mʌnθs?" hi fɹaʊnd. "weɪt. ɪf jə boʊθ daɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ, haʊ dɪd ðə stɔɹi ɡɛɾ aʊt?"

"You reconsidering?" she asked. ''No," he said. "But when we get out, Moiraine better bloody appreciate this! Two months?" He frowned. "Wait. If you both died in there, how did the story get out?"

ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "nɛvɝ dɪd faɪn aʊt. pɝhæps wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ juz ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz tə æsk.

She shrugged. "Never did find out. Perhaps one of the Aes Sedai used their questions to ask.

ɛvɹiwʌn nu aɪd ɡɔn ɪn. aɪ wɑz kɔl dʒɛθɑɹi mundənsɝ ðɛn. jəɹ ʃʊɹ juv nɛvɝ hɝd ðə stɔɹi?" hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn. ʃi saɪd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk. wɛl, nɑɾ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə teɪlz əbaʊɾ əɹ kəd lɪv ɑn fɝɛvɝ, bʌt ʃid θɔt ðət wʌn wəd stæn fəɹ ə fju mɔɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz. ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ mʌɡ tə dʒɹɪŋk ðə læst ə hɝ mɪlk. ðə mʌɡ nɛvɝ ɡɑt ðɛɹ. ʃi fɹoʊz wən ʃi fɛlt ə dʒoʊlt ʌv ɪmoʊʃən fɹəm ɪleɪn. æŋɡɝ, fjʊɹi, peɪn.

Everyone knew I'd gone in. I was called Jethari Moondancer then. You're sure you've never heard the story?" He shook his head again. She sighed, settling back. Well, not every one of the tales about her could live on forever, but she'd thought that one would stand for a few more generations. She raised her mug to drink the last of her milk. The mug never got there. She froze when she felt a jolt of emotion from Elayne. Anger, fury, pain.

bɝdʒɪt slæm ðə mʌɡ daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ðən θɹu kɔɪnz daʊn ən stʊɾ ʌp, kɝsɪŋ.

Birgitte slammed the mug down on the table, then threw coins down and stood up, cursing.

"wʌt?" mæt sɛd, ɑn ɪz fiɾ ɪn ən aɪɛblɪŋk. "ɪleɪn. ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. əɡɛn. ʃiz hɝt."

"What?" Mat said, on his feet in an eyeblink. "Elayne. In trouble. Again. She's hurt."

"blʌɾi æʃəz," mæt snæpt, ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪz koʊɾ ən stæf əz ðeɪ ɹæn fəɹ ði ɛɡzɪt.

"Bloody ashes," Mat snapped, grabbing his coat and staff as they ran for the exit.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi


CHAPTER 23

fɑkshɛdz


Foxheads

ɪleɪn tɝn ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ mədæljən ɝaʊn ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, tʃɹeɪsɪŋ ðə fɑksəz hɛd wɝkt ɪndə ðə fɹʌnt. əz wɪð mɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl ɪɡzækli wʌt kaɪndə mɛɾəl hæd bɪn juz tə kɹieɪɾ ɪɾ ɝɪdʒənəli. ʃi səspɛktəd sɪlvɝ, wɪð ðə sɛnsɪz ə hɝ tælənt. haʊɛvɝ, ðə mədæljən wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɪlvɝ. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, sʌmθɪŋ nu.

Elayne turned the strange medallion around in her fingers, tracing the fox's head worked into the front. As with many ter'angreal, it was difficult to tell exactly what kind of metal had been used to create it originally. She suspected silver, with the senses of her Talent. However, the medallion was no longer silver. It was something else, something new.

ðə sɔŋməstʃɹəs ə ðə lʌki mænz θiəɾɝ tʃɹup kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ sɔŋ. ɪt wɑz bjuɾəfəl, pjʊɹ ən haɪ. ɪleɪn sæɾ ɑn ə kʊʃən tʃɛɹ ɑn ðə ɹaɪt saɪɾ ə ðə hɔl, wɪtʃ hæd bɪn ɹipɝpoʊzd wɪð ə ɹeɪzd ɛɹiə ət ðə fɹʌn fəɹ ðə pleɪɝz. ə pɛɹ ə bɝdʒɪts ɡɑɹdz stʊd bɪhaɪn hɝ.

The songmistress of the Lucky Man's Theater Troop continued her song. It was beautiful, pure and high. Elayne sat on a cushioned chair on the right side of the hall, which had been repurposed with a raised area at the front for the players. A pair of Birgitte's Guards stood behind her.

ðə ɹum wɑz dɪm, lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ə laɪn ə smɔl flɪkɝɪŋ læmps sɛt bɪhaɪn blu ɡlæs ɪn ælkoʊvz ɑn ðə wɔlz. ðə blu laɪt wɑz oʊvɝwɛlm baɪ ðə bɝnɪŋ jɛloʊ læntɝnz sɛɾ ɝaʊn ðə fɹʌn ə ðə plætfɔɹm.

The room was dim, lit only by a line of small flickering lamps set behind blue glass in alcoves on the walls. The blue light was overwhelmed by the burning yellow lanterns set around the front of the platform.

ɪleɪn wɑz bɛɹli peɪɪŋ ətɛnʃən. ʃi hæɾ ɔfən lɪsən tə "ðə dɛθ ə pɹɪnsɛs wælɪʃən"

Elayne was barely paying attention. She had often listened to "The Death of Princess Walishen"

əz ə bæləd, ən dɪdn ɹɪli si ðə pɔɪn ʌv æɾɪŋ wɝdz tə ɪɾ ən dɪfɹən pleɪɝz, ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒʌs hævɪŋ wʌn bɑɹd də ði ɪntaɪɝ θɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɛlɹinz feɪvɹɪt bæləd, ən ðə feɪvɝəbəl nuz aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin əbaʊt ðiz pleɪɝz - wɪtʃ noʊbəlz ðəɹ hæd ɹisənli dɪskʌvɝd - hæd mɛni ʌv ðə noʊbəlz ɪn ændɝ bʌzɪŋ. hɛns ðɪs ivnɪŋ. ɛlɹin hæd kʌm əɾ ɪleɪnz ɪnvɪteɪʃən; laɪkli ʃi wɑz ɪntʃɹiɡd. waɪ hæɾ ɪleɪn bɪn soʊ ɑdeɪʃəs əz tə ɪnvaɪt hɝ? sun, in wəd teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ə hævɪŋ ɛlɹin hɪɹ. bʌt nɑt kwaɪt jɛt. lɛt ðə wɝnən ɛndʒɔɪ ðə pɹədʌkʃən fɝst. ʃid bi ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə pəlɪɾəkəl æmbʊʃ.

as a ballad, and didn't really see the point of adding words to it and different players, instead of just having one bard do the entire thing. But it was Ellorien's favorite ballad, and the favorable news out of Cairhien about these players - which nobles there had recently discovered - had many of the nobles in Andor buzzing. Hence this evening. Ellorien had come at Elayne's invitation; likely she was intrigued. Why had Elayne been so audacious as to invite her? Soon, Eayne would take advantage of having Ellorien here. But not quite yet. Let the wornan enjoy the production first. She'd be expecting a political ambush.

ʃid weɪt fəɹ ɪleɪn tə wɔk oʊvɝ ən sɪɾ ɪn wʌn ðə sits nɪɹ hɝ, əɹ pɝ-hæps sɛn ə sɝvənt wɪð ən ɔfɝɪleɪn dɪd niðɝ, ɪnstɛd sɪɾɪŋ ən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə fɑkshɛd tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ɪt wɑz ə kɑmplɛks wɝk ʌv ɑɹt, dɪspaɪt biɪŋ oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl, sɑləd pis ə mɛɾəl. ʃi kəd fil ðə wivz ðət hæd bɪn juz tə kɹieɪɾ ɪt. ɪts ɪntʃɹi-keɪsi wɑz fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə sɪmplɪsəɾi ʌv ðə twɪstəd dʒɹim ɹɪŋz. ʃi wɑz duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹipɹədus ðə mədæljən. ʃi kæɹiɾ ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ wʌn ə hɝ feɪld ətɛmps. ʃid hæd kɑpiz kæs fəɹ hɝ, əz pɹɪsaɪs ɪn dɪteɪl əz əɹ sɪlvɝsmɪθs kəd kɹieɪt, ðoʊ ʃi sʌs-pɛktɪd ðə fɔɹm wɑz nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ði əmaʊn ə sɪlvɝ sim tə bi, fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt nɑt ðə ʃeɪp ðət sɪlvɝ tʊk.

She'd wait for Elayne to walk over and sit in one the seats near her, or per-haps send a servant with an offer.Elayne did neither, instead sitting and regarding the foxhead ter'angreal, It was a complex work of art, despite being only a single, solid piece of metal. She could feel the weaves that had been used to create it. Its intri-cacy was far beyond the simplicity of the twisted dream rings. She was doing something wrong in trying to reproduce the medallion. She carried in her pouch one of her failed attempts. She'd had copies cast for her, as precise in detail as her silversmiths could create, though she sus-pected the form was not important. The amount of silver seemed to be, for some reason, but not the shape that silver took.

ʃid ɡɑɾən kloʊz. ðə kɑpi ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ dɪdnt wɝk pɝfəkli. lɛs paʊɝfəl wivz slɪɾ ɔf ɛniwʌn hoʊldɪŋ ɪt, bʌt vɛɹi paʊɝfəl wʌnz kəd nɑt bi dɪflɛktɪd fəɹ səm ɹizən. ænd, mɔɹ pɹɑbləmæɾɪk, ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə tʃænəl waɪl tʌtʃɪŋ ðə kɑpi.

She'd gotten close. The copy in her pouch didn't work perfectly. Less powerful weaves slid off anyone holding it, but very powerful ones could not be deflected for some reason. And, more problematic, it was impossible to channel while touching the copy.

ʃi kəd tʃænəl waɪl hoʊldɪŋ ði ɝɪdʒənəl. ɪndid, ʃid bɪn ɡɪɾi wən ʃid dɪskʌvɝd ðət hoʊldɪŋ ðə mədæljən dɪdn ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð əɹ wivz əɾ ɔl. biɪŋ pɹɛɡnən dɪd - ðət wɑz stɪl ə sɔɹs ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən tə hɝ - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə hoʊl ðə fɑkshɛɾ ən tʃænəl.

She could channel while holding the original. Indeed, she'd been giddy when she'd discovered that holding the medallion didn't interfere with her weaves at all. Being pregnant did - that was still a source of frustration to her - but it was possible to hold the foxhead and channel.

bʌt nɑt ðə kɑpi. ʃi hædnt ɡɑɾən ɪt kwaɪt ɹaɪt. ænd, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hɝ taɪm wɑz slɪm. mæt wəd niɾ ɪz mədæljən bæk sun.

But not the copy. She hadn't gotten it quite right. And, unfortunately, her time was slim. Mat would need his medallion back soon.

ʃi tʊk aʊt ðə feɪk ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə sit bɪsaɪd hɝ, ðən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən woʊv spɪɹət.

She took out the fake and set it on the seat beside her, then embraced the Source and wove Spirit.

sɛvɹəl ə ðə kɪn, ə ɡɹup ə hum wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə pɹədʌkʃən səm sits tə ðə saɪd, ɡlænst ʌp əɾ əɹ əz ʃi dɪd soʊ. moʊst wɝ tu dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ ðə sɔŋ.

Several of the Kin, a group of whom were watching the production some seats to the side, glanced up at her as she did so. Most were too distracted by the song.

ɪleɪn ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ən tʌtʃt ðə mədæljən. ɪmiɾiətli, hɝ wivz ənɹævəld ən ðə sɔɹs wɪŋkt əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. mʌtʃ əz ɪf ə ʃil hæd bɪn pleɪst oʊvɝ hɝ.

Elayne reached over and touched the medallion. Immediately, her weaves unraveled and the source winked away from her. Much as if a shield had been placed over her.

ʃi saɪɾ əz ðə sɔŋ ɹitʃt ɪts haɪts. ðə kɑpi wɑz soʊ kloʊz, jɛt soʊ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ʃid nɛvɝ wɛɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðət pɹɪvɛntɪɾ əɹ fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə sɔɹs, nɑɾ ivən fəɹ ðə pɹətɛkʃən ɪɾ ɔfɝd.

She sighed as the song reached its heights. The copy was so close, yet so frustrating at the same time. She'd never wear something that prevented her from touching the Source, not even for the protection it offered.

stɪl, ɪt wɑz nɑt kəmplitli jusləs. ʃi kəd ɡɪv ə kɑpi tə bɝdʒɪt, pɝhæps, ən ə fju ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn kæptənz. ɪt wʊdn də fəɹ əɹ tə kɹieɪt tu mɛni ʌv ðiz. nɑt wən ðeɪ kəd bi juz soʊ ɪfɛktɪvli əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Still, it was not completely useless. She could give a copy to Birgitte, perhaps, and a few of the Guardsmen captains. It wouldn't do for her to create too many of these. Not when they could be used so effectively against Aes Sedai.

kəd ʃi, pɝhæps, ɡɪv wʌn ə ðə kɑpiz tə mæt? hid nɛvɝ noʊ, sɪns i kʊdn tʃænəl hɪmsɛlf. . . .

Could she, perhaps, give one of the copies to Mat? He'd never know, since he couldn't channel himself. . . .

noʊ, ʃi θɔt, skwɑʃɪŋ ðət tɛmteɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ɪt kəd flaɪ tu haɪ.

No, she thought, squashing that temptation before it could fly too high.

ʃi hæd pɹɑməs tə ɹɪtɝn mæts mədæljən, ən ʃi wʊd. nɑt səm kɑpi ðət dɪdnt wɝk əz wɛl. ʃi tʌk boʊθ mədæljənz ɪndə hɝ dʒɹɛs pɑkt. naʊ ðət ʃi nu ʃi kəd ɡɛt mæt tə pɑɹt wɪð ɪz mədæljən, pɝhæps ʃi kəd bʊli hɪm ɪndə ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ mɔɹ taɪm. ðoʊ ðə pɹɛz-ɛns ə ðə ɡoʊlɑɹn dɪd wɝi hɝ. haʊ tə dil wɪð ðə θɪŋ? pɝhæps kɑpiz ə ðə mədæljən fəɹ ɔl əɹ ɡɑɹdz wʊdn bi ə bæɾ aɪdiə æftɝ ɔl.

She had promised to return Mat's medallion, and she would. Not some copy that didn't work as well. She tucked both medallions into her dress pocked. Now that she knew she could get Mat to part with his medallion, perhaps she could bully him into giving her more time. Though the pres-ence of the gholarn did worry her. How to deal with the thing? Perhaps copies of the medallion for all her guards wouldn't be a bad idea after all.

ðə sɔŋ fɪnɪʃt, ðə faɪnəl, haɪ-pɪtʃt noʊt dwɪndəlɪŋ laɪk ə kændəl ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv wɪk. ði ɛn ə ðə pleɪ keɪm ʃɔɹtli æftɝwɝd, mɛn ɪn waɪt mæsks dʒʌmpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs. ə bɹɪljən laɪt flæʃt, sʌmθɪŋ θɹoʊn ɪndə wʌn ə ðə læntɝnz, ən wən ɪt feɪɾəd əɡɛn, wælɪʃən leɪ dɛɾ ɑn ðə steɪdʒ, ðə bɛl ə hɝ ɹɛd dʒɹɛs spleɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ laɪk spɪl blʌd.

The song finished, the final, high-pitched note dwindling like a candle running out of wick. The end of the play came shortly afterward, men in white masks jumping out of the darkness. A brilliant light flashed, something thrown into one of the lanterns, and when it faded again, Walishen lay dead on the stage, the bell of her red dress splayed around her like spilled blood.

ði ɑɾiəns stʊd tə klæp. moʊst ə ðɛm wɝ kɪn, ðoʊ nɑɾ ə fju wɝ ətɛndəns ə ði ʌðɝ haɪ sits u hæd bɪn ɪnvaɪɾəd. ɔl ə ðoʊz wɝ səpɔɹɾɝz ə hɝz. daɪɛlɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, ən jʌŋ kɑneɪl nɔɹθən ən ði ikwəli jʌŋ - bʌt twaɪs əz pɹaʊd - kæɾəlɪn hɛvɪn.

The audience stood to clap. Most of them were Kin, though not a few were attendants of the other High Seats who had been invited. All of those were supporters of hers. Dyelin, of course, and young Conail Northan and the equally young - but twice as proud - Catalyn Haevin.

ðə faɪnəl noʊbəl hɪɹ wɑz sɪivɑz kɝən. wʌt tə meɪk ə hɝ? ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, slɪpɪŋ ðə feɪk fɑkshɛɾ ɪndə hɝ paʊtʃ ən lɛndɪŋ ə dɪmjʊɹ klæp tə ði ʌðɝ ækəleɪdz. ðə pleɪɝz wəd bi foʊkəst oʊnli ɑn hɝ. ɪf ʃi dɪdnt ɡɪv səm saɪn ʌv əpɹuvəl, ðeɪd fɹɛt ði ɪntaɪɝ naɪt.

The final noble here was Syivase Caeren. What to make of her? Elayne shook her head, slipping the fake foxhead into her pouch and lending a demure clap to the other accolades. The players would be focused only on her. If she didn't give some sign of approval, they'd fret the entire night.

ðət dʌn, ɪleɪn meɪɾ əɹ weɪ aʊt tə ə nɪɹbaɪ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wɪtʃ wɑz fɝnɪʃt wɪð pæɾəd, θɪk-ɑɹm tʃɛɹz fəɹ ɹɪlæks kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ðəɹ wɑz ə bɑɹ ət ðə saɪd, mæn baɪ ə sɝvɪŋ mæn ɪn ə kɹɪsp ɹɛɾ ən waɪt junəfɔɹm. hi stʊd wɪð hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, weɪɾɪŋ ɹɪspɛkfəli əz pipəl æmbəld ɪn. ɛlɹin wɑzn ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs - ɪt wɑz beɪsɪk kɝɾəsi fəɹ ə ɡɛs tə weɪt fəɹ ðə hoʊs tə wɪðdʒɹɔ fɝst. ðoʊ ɛlɹin ən ɪleɪn wɝn ɑn ðə bɛst ə tɝmz, ɪt wʊdn də tə ʃoʊ pʊɹ mænɝz.

That done, Elayne made her way out to a nearby sitting room, which was furnished with padded, thick-armed chairs for relaxed conversation. There was a bar at the side, manned by a serving man in a crisp red and white uniform. He stood with hands behind his back, waiting respectfully as people ambled in. Ellorien wasn't there, of course - it was basic courtesy for a guest to wait for the host to withdraw first. Though Ellorien and Elayne weren't on the best of terms, it wouldn't do to show poor manners.

sun æftɝ ɪleɪn ɝaɪvd, ɛlɹin tʃɹeɪld ɪn. ðə plʌmp wʊmən wɑz tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð wʌn ə ðə kɪnswɪmən, pɔɪntɪdli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə haɪ sits u wɔk nɪɹ hɝ. hɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃən saʊndəd fɔɹst. ʃi pɹɑbli cʊɾə bɪn ɪkspɛktəd tə əvɔɪd ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ɪntaɪɝli, bʌɾ ɪleɪn nu ðət ðə wʊmən wəd wɑnə meɪk sɝɾən tə ɪkspɹɛs ðət ʃi hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd əɹ maɪn əbaʊt haʊs tʃɹəkənd.

Soon after Elayne arrived, Ellorien trailed in. The plump woman was chatting with one of the Kinswomen, pointedly ignoring the High Seats who walked near her. Her conversation sounded forced. She probably could have been expected to avoid the sitting room entirely, but Elayne knew that the woman would want to make certain to express that she had not changed her mind about House Trakand.

ɪleɪn smaɪld, bʌt dɪd nɑɾ əpɹoʊtʃ ðə wʊmən, ɪnstɛd tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd sɪivɑz əz ʃi ɛntɝd. ʌv miɾiəm bɪld, ðə blu-aɪd ɡɝl maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪɾi, seɪv fəɹ ðəɾ ɪkspɹɛʃənləs lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs. nɑɾ ɪmoʊʃənləs, laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. kəmplitli ɪkspɹɛʃənləs. ɪt səmtaɪmz sim laɪk sɪivɑz wɑz ə dʒɹɛsɪŋ dʌmi sɛɾ ʌp fəɹ dɪspleɪ. bʌt ðɛn, ɑn ʌðɝ əkeɪʒənz, ʃid ʃoʊ ə hɪɾən dɛpθ, ə kʌnɪŋ dip daʊn.

Elayne smiled, but did not approach the woman, instead turning toward Syivase as she entered. Of medium build, the blue-eyed girl might have been pretty, save for that expressionless look on her face. Not emotionless, like an Aes Sedai. Completely expressionless. It sometimes seemed like Syivase was a dressing dummy set up for display. But then, on other occasions, she'd show a hidden depth, a cunning deep down.

θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən, jəɹ mædʒəsti," sɪivɑz sɛɾ ivənli, hɝ vɔɪs ə feɪnli ɪɹi mɑnətoʊn. "ɪt wɑz moʊst ɛnlaɪɾənɪŋ."

Thank you for the invitation, Your Majesty," Syivase said evenly, her voice a faintly eerie monotone. "It was most enlightening."

ɛnlaɪɾənɪŋ?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ ʃəd hoʊp ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɛndʒɔɪəbəl."

Enlightening?" Elayne said. "I should hope that it was enjoyable."

sɪivɑz sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɛlɹin, ən hɪɹ ʃi faɪnəli ʃoʊd səm ɪmoʊʃən. ən aɪsi kaɪndə dɪslaɪk, ðə kaɪn ðət ɡeɪv jə ə ʃɪvɝ. "waɪ ɪnvaɪt hɝ, jəɹ mædʒəsti?"

Syivase said nothing. She glanced at Ellorien, and here she finally showed some emotion. An icy kind of dislike, the kind that gave you a shiver. "Why invite her, Your Majesty?"

"haʊs kɝən wɑz əɾ ɑdz wɪð tʃɹəkənd wʌns, tu," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ʌv tɛn, ðoʊz huz lɔɪəlti ɪz moʊs dɪfəkəl tə wɪn ɑɹ ðə moʊs væljəbəl wʌns ɪts jʊɹz."

"House Caeren was at odds with Trakand once, too," Elayne said, "Of ten, those whose loyalty is most difficult to win are the most valuable once it is yours."

"ʃi wɪl nɑt səpɔɹt ju, jəɹ mædʒəsti," sɪlveɪs sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs stɪl tu kɑm. "nɑɾ æftɝ wʌt jəɹ mʌðɝ dɪd."

"She will not support you, Your Majesty," Sylvase said, her voice still too calm. "Not after what your mother did."

"wɛn maɪ mʌðɝ tʊk ðə θɹoʊn jɪɹz əɡoʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɾ ɛlɹin, "ðɛɹ wɝ səm haʊsəz ɪt wɑz sɛd ʃid nɛvɝ wɪn oʊvɝ ən jɛt ʃi dɪd."

"When my mother took the throne years ago," Elayne said, glancing over at Ellorien, "there were some Houses it was said she'd never win over And yet she did."

"soʊ? jə ɔlɹɛɾi hæv ɪnʌf səpɔɹt, jəɹ mædʒəsti. juv hæd jəɹ vɪktɝi."

"So? You already have enough support, Your Majesty. You've had your victory."

"wʌn ə ðɛm."

"One of them."

ʃi lɛf ðə ɹɛst ənsɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə dɛɾ ʌv ɑnɝ oʊd tə haʊs tʃɹæmən. kɔɹɾɪŋ ɛlɹinz əpɹuvəl wɑzn mɪɹli əbaʊt stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt ɹɪpɛɹɪŋ ɹɪfs kɑz baɪ ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ waɪl ʌndɝ ði ɪnfluəns ʌv ɡeɪbɹəl. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ əɹ haʊsəz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən, əbaʊɾ ənduɪŋ ðə ɹɔŋz ðət kəd bi əndʌn.

She left the rest unsaid. There was a debt of honor owed to House Traemane. Courting Ellorien's approval wasn't merely about strengthening the Lion Throne. It was about repairing rifts caused by Elayne's mother while under the influence of Gaebril. It was about recovering her House's reputation, about undoing the wrongs that could be undone.

sɪlveɪs wəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. ɪleɪn hæd lɝn əbaʊt ðə pʊɹ ɡɝlz tʃaɪldhʊd; ðɪs wʌn wəd nɑt pʊt mʌtʃ stɑk ɪn ði ɑnɝ ʌv ə haɪ sit. sɪlveɪs sim tə bɪliv ɪn oʊnli tu θɪŋz:

Sylvase would not understand that. Elayne had learned about the poor girl's childhood; this one would not put much stock in the honor of a High Seat. Sylvase seemed to believe in only two things:

paʊɝ ən vɛnʒəns. soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪn ən kəd bi ɡaɪɾəd, ʃi wəd nɑt bi ə laɪəbɪlɪɾi. bʌt ʃi wəd nɛvɝ bi ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə haʊs tʃɹəkən ðət sʌmwʌn laɪk daɪɛlɪn wɑz.

power and vengeance. So long as she supported Elayne and could be guided, she would not be a liability. But she would never be the strength to House Trakand that someone like Dyelin was.

"haʊ ɪz maɪ sɛkɹətɛɹi sɝvɪŋ jəɹ nidz, jəɹ mædʒəsti?" sɪlveɪs æskt.

"How is my secretary serving your needs, Your Majesty?" Sylvase asked.

"wɛl ɪnʌf, aɪ səpoʊz," ɪleɪn sɛd. soʊ fɑɹ, hi hædn pɹədust ɛniθɪŋ ə vælju, ðoʊ ɪleɪn hædnt ɡɪvən ɪm liv tə də ɛniθɪŋ tu dʒɹæstɪk dʊɹɪŋ ɪz kwɛstʃənɪŋ. ʃi wɑz tʃɹæpt ɪn ə kənʌnʒɹəm. ʃid bɪn hʌntɪŋ ðɪs ɡɹup ə blæk ədʒɑ fəɹ wʌt sim laɪk fɝɛvɝ. ʃi faɪnəli hæɾ əm . . . bʌt wʌd ʃi də wɪð ðɛm?

"Well enough, I suppose," Elayne said. So far, he hadn't produced anything of value, though Elayne hadn't given him leave to do anything too drastic during his questioning. She was trapped in a conundrum. She'd been hunting this group of Black Ajah for what seemed like forever. She finally had them . . . but what did she do with them?

bɝdʒɪt hæd teɪkən ðə kæptɪvz əlaɪv ɑstɛnsəbli soʊ ðət ðeɪ kəd bi kwɛstʃənd, ðən tʃɹaɪd baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. bʌt ðət mɛn ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɹizən tə spik; ðeɪ nu ðɛɹ ʌltəməɾ ɛnd wəd bi ɛksəkjuʃən. soʊ ɪleɪn iðɝ hæd tə bi wɪlɪŋ tə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðɛm, əɹ ʃi hæd tə lɛt ðə kwɛstʃənɝ teɪk ɪkstʃɹim mɛʒɝz.

Birgitte had taken the captives alive ostensibly so that they could be questioned, then tried by the White Tower. But that meant they had no reason to speak; they knew their ultimate end would be execution. So Elayne either had to be willing to bargain with them, or she had to let the questioner take extreme measures.

ə kwin hæd tə bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə əlaʊ ðiz θɪŋz. əɹ ðət wɑz wʌɾ əɹ titʃɝz ən tuɾɝz hæɾ ɪkspleɪnd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kwɛstʃən əz tə ðə ɡɪlt ə ðiz wɪmən, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn ɪnʌf tə ɝn ðɛmsɛlvz dɛθ ə dʌzən taɪmz oʊvɝ. ɪleɪn wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ fɑɹ ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə dɪsɛnd, haʊɛvɝ, tə pɹaɪ ðɛɹ sikɹəts fɹi.

A queen had to be hard enough to allow these things. Or that was what her teachers and tutors had explained. There was no question as to the guilt of these women, and they had already done enough to earn themselves death a dozen times over. Elayne wasn't certain how far she herself was willing to descend, however, to pry their secrets free.

bɪsaɪdz, wəd ðəɾ æktʃəli  də ɛni ɡʊd? ɪspæn hæd hæd kaɪndə ə kəmpʌlʃən əɹ oʊðz baɪndɪŋ hɝ; ðiz wɝ laɪkli tə hæv ðə seɪm. wəd ðeɪ bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪvil ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl? ɪf oʊnli ðəɹ wɝ ə weɪ tə...

Besides, would that actually do any good? Ispan had had some kind of Compulsion or oaths binding her; these were likely to have the same. Would they be able to reveal anything useful? If only there were a way to...

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, mɪsɪŋ sɪlveɪsəz nɛks kɑmɛn əz ə θɔɾ əkɝd tə hɝ. bɝdʒɪt wʊdn laɪk ɪt, ʌv kɔɹs. bɝdʒɪt dɪdn laɪk ɛniθɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd fɛl bɝdʒɪt muv ɔf aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs sʌmwɛɹ, pɝhæps duɪŋ ɹaʊnz ə ðə ɡɑɹd poʊsts aʊtsaɪd.

She hesitated, missing Sylvase's next comment as a thought occurred to her. Birgitte wouldn't like it, of course. Birgitte didn't like anything. But Elayne had felt Birgitte move off out of the Palace somewhere, perhaps doing rounds of the guard posts outside.

"ɪkskjus mi, sɪlveɪs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ dʒʌst ɹɪkɔl sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ aɪ æbsəlutli mʌs du."

"Excuse me, Sylvase," Elayne said. "I just recalled something that I absolutely must do."

"ʌv kɔɹs, jəɹ mædʒəsti," ðə ɡɝl sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt, ɔlmoʊst ɪnhjumən vɔɪs.

"Of course, Your Majesty," the girl said in a flat, almost inhuman voice.

ɪleɪn muv fɹəm hɝ, ðən kwɪkli ɡɹiɾəd - ən beɪd ɡʊɾ iv- nɪŋ. - tə ði ʌðɝz. kɑneɪl lʊk bɔɹd. hid kʌm kəz ɪt hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ə hɪm. daɪɛlɪn wɑz əɹ juʒəwəl plɛzənt, jɛt kɛɹfəl, sɛlf. ɪleɪn əvɔɪɾəd ɛlɹin. ʃi ɡɹiɾəd ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪn ðə ɹum ə noʊt. wʌns fɪnɪʃt, ʃi bɪɡæn tə wɔk təwɔɹd ði ɛɡzɪt.

Elayne moved from her, then quickly greeted - and bade good eve- ning. - to the others. Conail looked bored. He'd come because it had been expected of him. Dyelin was her usual pleasant, yet careful, self. Elayne avoided Ellorien. She greeted everyone else in the room of note. Once finished, she began to walk toward the exit.

"ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd," ɛlɹin kɔld aʊt.

"Elayne Trakand," Ellorien called out.

ɪleɪn pɔzd, smaɪlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. ʃi tɝnd, waɪpɪŋ əɹ feɪs ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən kælkjəleɪɾəd kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. "jɛs, leɪɾi ɛlɹin?"

Elayne paused, smiling to herself. She turned, wiping her face of anything other than calculated curiosity. "Yes, Lady Ellorien?"

"hæv jə ɪnvaɪɾəd mi hɪɹ oʊnli tə ɪɡnɔɹ mi?" ðə wʊmən dɪmændəd fɹəm əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. ʌðɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃənz ɡɹu kwaɪət.

"Have you invited me here only to ignore me?" the woman demanded from across the room. Other conversations grew quiet.

"nɑɾ əɾ ɔl," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɑz mɪɹli ʌndɝ ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət jə wəɾ əv ə mɔɹ plɛzən taɪm ɪf aɪ dɪd nɑt fɔɹs jə tə ɪntɝækt wɪð mi. ðɪs ivnɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ ɪntɛndəd fəɹ pəlɪɾəkəl pɝpəsəz."

"Not at all," Elayne said. "I was merely under the impression that you would have a more pleasant time if I did not force you to interact with me. This evening was not intended for political purposes."

ɛlɹin fɹaʊnd. "wɛl wʌt wɑz ɪt fɔɹ, ðɛn?"

Ellorien frowned. "Well what was it for, then?"

"tə ɛndʒɔɪ ə ɡʊd bæləd, leɪɾi ɛlɹin," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ænd, pɝhæps, tə ɹimaɪn jə ʌv deɪz wən jə ɔfən ɛndʒɔɪɾ ɛntɝteɪnmən ɪn ðə kʌmpəni ʌv haʊs tʃɹəkənd." ʃi smaɪld ən nɑɾəd slaɪtli, ðən lɛft.

"To enjoy a good ballad, Lady Ellorien," Elayne said. "And, perhaps, to remind you of days when you often enjoyed entertainment in the company of House Trakand." She smiled and nodded slightly, then left.

lɛɾ əɹ θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt, ɪleɪn θɔt wɪð sæɾəsfækʃən. ɛlɹin hæd noʊ daʊt hɝd ðət ɡeɪbɹəl hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ðə wʊmən maɪt nɑt bɪliv ɪt, bʌt pɝhæps ʃi wəd ɹikɔl ðə jɪɹz ə ɹɪspɛkt ʃi ən mɔɹɡeɪs hæd ʃoʊn wʌn ənʌðɝ. ʃəɾ ə fju ʃɔɹt mʌnθs bi kɑz tə fɝɡɛt jɪɹz ə fɹɛndʃɪp?

Let her think about that, Elayne thought with satisfaction. Ellorien had no doubt heard that Gaebril had been one of the Forsaken. The woman might not believe it, but perhaps she would recall the years of respect she and Morgase had shown one another. Should a few short months be cause to forget years of friendship?

ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stɛps aʊɾ ə ðə laʊnʒ, ɪleɪn faʊn keɪlə bɛnt, wʌn ə bɝdʒɪts ɡɑɹdzwʊmən kæptənz. ðə læŋki faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən wɑz tʃæɾɪŋ eɪmiəbli wɪð ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn, boʊθ ə hum sim kwaɪɾ iɡɝ tə ɡeɪn əɹ feɪvɝ. ɔl θɹi snæp tə ətɛnʃən wən ðeɪ noʊɾəst ɪleɪn.

At the bottom of the steps out of the lounge, Elayne found Kaila Bent, one of Birgitte's Guardswoman captains. The lanky fire-haired woman was chatting amiably with a pair of Guardsmen, both of whom seemed quite eager to gain her favor. All three snapped to attention when they noticed Elayne.

"wɛɹ dɪd bɝdʒɪt ɡoʊ?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"Where did Birgitte go?" Elayne asked.

"ʃi wɛn tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾ ə dɪstɝbəns ət ðə ɡeɪts, jəɹ mædʒəsti,"

"She went to investigate a disturbance at the gates, Your Majesty,"

keɪlə sɛd. "aɪv hæd wɝd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ. ðət mɝsənɛɹi kæptən u keɪm tə vɪzət jə ɝliɝ tʃɹaɪd tə snik ɑntu ðə pæləs ɡɹaʊnz. kæp-teɪn bɝdʒɪɾ ɪz kwɛstʃənɪŋ hɪm."

Kaila said. "I've had word that it was nothing. That mercenary captain who came to visit you earlier tried to sneak onto the palace grounds. Cap-tain Birgitte is questioning him."

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "ju min meɪtʃɹim kɔθən?"

Elayne raised an eyebrow. "You mean Matrim Cauthon?"

ðə wʊmən nɑɾəd.

The woman nodded.

"ʃiz 'kwɛstʃənɪŋ' hɪm?" "ðæts wʌɾ aɪ hɝd, jəɹ mædʒəsti," keɪlə ɹɪplaɪd.

"She's 'questioning' him?" "That's what I heard, Your Majesty," Kaila replied.

"ðæt minz ðə tu ʌv əm əv ɡɔn aʊt fəɹ dʒɹɪŋks," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪð ə saɪ. laɪt, ðɪs wɑz ə bæd taɪm fəɹ ɪt.

"That means the two of them have gone out for drinks," Elayne said with a sigh. Light, this was a bad time for it.

əɹ wɑz ɪɾ ə ɡʊd taɪm? bɝdʒɪt kʊdn əbdʒɛk tə ɪleɪnz plæn fəɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪf ʃi wɑz aʊt wɪð mæt. ɪleɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf smaɪlɪŋ. "kæptən bɛnt, jə ɑɹ wɪð mi." ʃi lɛf ðə θiəɾɝ ɹumz ən ɛntɝd ðə pæləs pɹɑpɝ. ðə wʊmən fɑloʊd, weɪvɪŋ fəɹ ðə skwɑɾ ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən stændɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ tə fɑloʊ.

Or was it a good time? Birgitte couldn't object to Elayne's plan for the Black Ajah if she was out with Mat. Elayne found herself smiling. "Captain Bent, you are with me." She left the theater rooms and entered the Palace proper. The woman followed, waving for the squad of Guardswomen standing in the hallway to follow.

smaɪlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn bɪɡæn ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz-wɪmən ɹæn ɔf tə dɪlɪvɝ ðɛm, ðoʊ ʃi lʊkt kənfjuzd ət ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ lɪst ə kəmænz. ɪleɪn meɪɾ əɹ weɪ tə hɝ ɹumz, ðən sæt daʊn, θɪŋkɪŋ. ʃi wəɾ əv tə muv kwɪkli. bɝdʒɪt wɑz ɪn ə sɝli mud; ɪleɪn kəd tɛl ðət θɹu ðə bɑnd.

Smiling to herself, Elayne began giving orders. One of the Guards-women ran off to deliver them, though she looked confused at the strange list of commands. Elayne made her way to her rooms, then sat down, thinking. She would have to move quickly. Birgitte was in a surly mood; Elayne could tell that through the bond.

ə sɝvən sun ɝaɪvd, kæɹiɪŋ ən ɪnvɛləpɪŋ blæk kloʊk. ɪleɪn dʒʌmpt ʌp ən slɪpt ɪɾ ɑn, ðən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. ɪt tʊk əɹ θɹi tʃɹaɪz! blʌɾi æʃəz, bʌt biɪŋ pɹɛɡnənt wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ səmtaɪmz.

A servant soon arrived, carrying an enveloping black cloak. Elayne jumped up and slipped it on, then embraced the Source. It took her three tries! Bloody ashes, but being pregnant was frustrating sometimes.

ʃi spʌn wivz ə faɪɝ ən ɛɹ ɝaʊn hɝ, juzɪŋ ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts tə meɪk hɝsɛlf lʊk tɔlɝ, mɔɹ ɪmpoʊzɪŋ. ʃi fɛtʃt əɹ dʒuəlɹi tʃɛst ən fɪʃt aʊɾ ə smɔl aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə siɾəd wʊmən ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn əɹ oʊn hɛɹ. ʃi juz ði æŋɡɹil tə pʊl əz mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪndə hɝ əz ʃi dɛɹd. tə ɛniwʌn wɑtʃɪŋ u kəd tʃænəl, ʃid lʊk ɪmpoʊzɪŋ ɪndid.

She spun weaves of Fire and Air around her, using the Mirror of Mists to make herself look taller, more imposing. She fetched her jewelry chest and fished out a small ivory carving of a seated woman shrouded in her own hair. She used the angreal to pull as much of the One Power into her as she dared. To anyone watching who could channel, she'd look imposing indeed.

ʃi ɡlæns bæk ət ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən. ðeɪ wɝ kənfjuzd, ɑbviəsli, ən stʊd wɪð ðɛɹ hænz ʌnkɑnʃəsli ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɹdz. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti?' keɪlə æskt.

She glanced back at the Guardswomen. They were confused, obviously, and stood with their hands unconsciously on their swords. "Your Majesty?' Kaila asked.

"haʊ də aɪ lʊk?" ɪleɪn sɛd, twikɪŋ əɹ wivz tə meɪk əɹ vɔɪs dipɝ.

"How do I look?" Elayne said, tweaking her weaves to make her voice deeper.

keɪləz aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾɝ. "laɪk ə θʌndɝhɛd ɡɪvən laɪf, jəɹ mædʒəsti."

Kaila's eyes opened wider. "Like a thunderhead given life, Your Majesty."

"ɪmpoʊzɪŋ, ðɛn?" ɪleɪn æskt, dʒʌmpɪŋ slaɪtli ət ðə deɪnʒɝəs, ɔlmoʊst ɪnhjumən saʊn ə hɝ vɔɪs. pɝfəkt!

"Imposing, then?" Elayne asked, jumping slightly at the dangerous, almost inhuman sound of her voice. Perfect!

"aɪd seɪ soʊ," ðə læŋki ɡɑɹdzwʊmən sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn wɪð wʌn hænd. "ðoʊ ðə slɪpɝz də spɔɪl ði ɪfɛkt."

"I'd say so," the lanky Guardswoman said, rubbing her chin with one hand. "Though the slippers do spoil the effect."

ɪleɪn ɡlæns daʊn, kɝsɪŋ ət ðə pɪŋk sɪlk. ʃi woʊv səm mɔɹ, meɪkɪŋ əɹ slɪpɝd fit vænɪʃ. ðə wiv wəd meɪk ɪɾ əpɪɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɹæpt ɪn ə pʌlsɪŋ ʃɹaʊɾ ə dɑɹknəs, kloʊk ən stʃɹæps ə blæk klɔθ flʌɾɝɪŋ ɹaʊn hɝ. hɝ feɪs wɑz hɪɾən kəmplitli ɪn blæknəs. əz ən æɾəd tʌtʃ, ʃi kɹieɪɾəd tu feɪnli ɡloʊɪŋ pɪks ə ɹɛd wɛɹ ði aɪz ʃəd bi. laɪk koʊlz ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ wɪð ə dip kɹɪmzən laɪt.

Elayne glanced down, cursing at the pink silk. She wove some more, making her slippered feet vanish. The weave would make it appear as if she were floating in the air, wrapped in a pulsing shroud of darkness, cloak and straps of black cloth fluttering round her. Her face was hidden completely in blackness. As an added touch, she created two faintly glowing picks of red where the eyes should be. Like coals radiating with a deep crimson light.

"laɪt pɹəzɝv ʌs," wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz wɪspɝd. ɪleɪn nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf, hɝ hɑɹt kwɪkənɪŋ ɪn ɪksaɪtmənt. ʃi wɑznt wɝid. ʃid bi seɪf. mɪnz vjuɪŋ pɹɑməs ðæt. ʃi ɹæn θɹu hɝ plænz əɡɛn. ðeɪ wɝ sɑləd. bʌt ðəɹ wəd bi oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə tɛst əm fəɹ sɝɾən.

"Light preserve us," one of the Guards whispered. Elayne nodded to herself, her heart quickening in excitement. She wasn't worried. She'd be safe. Min's viewing promised that. She ran through her plans again. They were solid. But there would be only one way to test them for certain.

ɪleɪn ɪnvɝɾɪd əɹ wivz ən taɪɾ əm ɔf. ðən ʃi tɝn tə ðə ɡɑɹdz. "tɝn aʊt ðə laɪts,"

Elayne inverted her weaves and tied them off. Then she turned to the Guards. "Turn out the lights,"

ʃi sɛd tə ðɛm, "æn ɹɪmeɪn pɝfəkli stɪl. əl ɹɪtɝn ʃɔɹtli."

she said to them, "and remain perfectly still. I will return shortly."

"bʌt - " keɪlə sɛd.

"But - " Kaila said.

"ðæɾ ɪz ən ɔɹɾɝ, ɡɑɹdzwʊmən," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli. "ju hæd bɛst oʊbeɪ ɪt."

"That is an order, Guardswoman," Elayne said firmly. "You had best obey it."

ðə wʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi laɪkli nu ðət bɝdʒɪt wəd nɛvɝ lɛt ðɪs hæpən. bʌt keɪlə wɑz nɑt bɝdʒɪt, θæŋkfəli. ʃi ɹɪlʌktənli ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ ən ðə laɪts ɪn ðə ɹum wɝ daʊst.

The woman hesitated. She likely knew that Birgitte would never let this happen. But Kaila was not Birgitte, thankfully. She reluctantly gave the order and the lights in the room were doused.

ɪleɪn ɹitʃt ɪndə hɝ pɑkəɾ ən tʊk aʊt ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən, ðə ɹil wʌn, ən hɛld ɪt hɪɾən ən tʌkt ɪn əɹ hænd. ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən kɹieɪɾəd ə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðə ɹɪbən ə laɪt wɑz bɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə blækən ɹum, ɡloʊɪŋ ən beɪðɪŋ əm ɪn ə peɪl ɡloʊ, laɪk munlaɪt. ɪɾ oʊpən ɪndə ə ɹum ðət wɑz sɪməlɝli dɑɹk.

Elayne reached into her pocket and took out the foxhead medallion, the real one, and held it hidden and tucked in her hand. She took a deep breath, then created a gateway. The ribbon of light was bright in the blackened room, glowing and bathing them in a pale glow, like moonlight. It opened into a room that was similarly dark.

ɪleɪn stɛp θɹu ən faʊn hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə pæləs dʌnʒənz, ɪn wʌn ə ðə sɛlz. ə wʊmən nɛlt ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə sɛl, bɪsaɪd ðə stɝɾi dɔɹ wɪð ə smɔl wɪndoʊ ət ðə tɑp, slɑɾɪd wɪð bɑɹz, ðət lɛɾ ɪn ði oʊnli laɪɾ ɪn ðə dæŋk sɛl. ðəɹ wɑz ə smɔl kɑt tə ɪleɪnz ɹaɪɾ ən ə bʌkət fəɹ ə tʃeɪmbɝ pɑt tə hɝ lɛft. ðə taɪni ɹum smɛld ə moʊld ən hjumən weɪst, ən ʃi kəd klɪɹli hɪɹ ðə skɹætʃɪŋ ə ɹæts nɪɹbaɪ. ɪt stɪl sim tu lævɪʃ kɔɹɾɝz fəɹ ðə wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ.

Elayne stepped through and found herself in the Palace dungeons, in one of the cells. A woman knelt on the far side of the cell, beside the sturdy door with a small window at the top, slotted with bars, that let in the only light in the dank cell. There was a small cot to Elayne's right and a bucket for a chamber pot to her left. The tiny room smelled of mold and human waste, and she could clearly hear the scratching of rats nearby. It still seemed too lavish quarters for the woman in front of her.

ɪleɪn hæd tʃoʊzən tʃɛzməl wɪð kælkjəleɪʃən. ðə wʊmən hæd sim tə hæv səm əθɔɹəɾi əmʌŋ ðə blæk, ən ʃi wɑz paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf ðət moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz wəd baʊ tə hɝ. bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæd simd mɔɹ pæʃənət ðən lɑdʒɪkəl, wən ɪleɪn hæd læst ɪnkaʊntɝd hɝ. ðət wəd bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Elayne had chosen Chesmal with calculation. The woman had seemed to have some authority among the Black, and she was powerful enough that most of the others would bow to her. But she also had seemed more passionate than logical, when Elayne had last encountered her. That would be important.

ðə tɔl, hænsəm wʊmən spʌn əz sun əz ɪleɪn ɛntɝd ðə sɛl. ɪleɪn hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ.

The tall, handsome woman spun as soon as Elayne entered the cell. Elayne held her breath.

blɛsədli, ði ækt wɝkt. tʃɛzməl θɹu hɝsɛlf tə ðə stʃɹɔ-kʌvɝd flɔɹ ə ðə sɛl.

Blessedly, the act worked. Chesmal threw herself to the straw-covered floor of the cell.

'ɡɹeɪt wʌn," ðə wʊmən hɪst. "aɪ hæd - " "saɪləns!" ɪleɪn ʃaʊɾəd, hɝ vɔɪs bumɪŋ.

'Great One," the woman hissed. "I had - " "Silence!" Elayne shouted, her voice booming.

tʃɛzməl kɹɪnʒd, ðən ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd, əz ɪf weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz aʊtsaɪd tə pik ɪn. ðəɹ wəd bi kɪnswɪmən ðəɹ tə hoʊl tʃɛzməlz ʃild; ɪleɪn kəd fil ðɛm. noʊbɑdi keɪm, dɪspaɪt ðə saʊnd. ðə kɪn wɝ fɑloʊɪŋ ɪleɪnz ɔɹɾɝz, ɑd ðoʊ ðoʊz ɔɹɾɝz wɝ.

Chesmal cringed, then glanced to the side, as if waiting for the Guards outside to peek in. There would be Kinswomen there to hold Chesmal's shield; Elayne could feel them. Nobody came, despite the sound. The Kin were following Elayne's orders, odd though those orders were.

"ju ɑɹ lɛs ðən ə ɹæt," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪð əɹ dɪsɡaɪz vɔɪs. "ju wɝ sɛn tə si tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ɡlɔɹi, bʌt wʌɾ əv jə dʌn? əlaʊd jɝsɛlf tə bi kæptʃɝd baɪ ðiz fulz, ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən?"

"You are less than a rat," Elayne said with her disguised voice. "You were sent to see to the Great Lord's glory, but what have you done? Allowed yourself to be captured by these fools, these children?"

tʃɛzməl weɪld, boʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf fɝðɝ. "aɪ æm dʌst, ɡɹeɪt wʌn. aɪm nʌθɪŋ! wɪv feɪl ju.

Chesmal wailed, bowing herself further. "I am dust, Great One. I am nothing! We have failed you.

pliz, də nɑt dɪstʃɹɔɪ mi!"

Please, do not destroy me!"

"ænd waɪ ʃʊdn aɪ?" ɪleɪn bɑɹkt. "ðə wɝk ə jəɹ pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɡɹup əz bɪn mɑɹkt wɪð feɪljɝ æftɝ feɪljɝ! wʌɾ əv jə dʌn ðət wəd pɑsəbli pɝsweɪd mi tə əlaʊ jə tə lɪv?"

"And why shouldn't I?" Elayne barked. "The work of your particular group has been marked with failure after failure! What have you done that would possibly persuade me to allow you to live?"

"wi hæv kɪl mɛni ʌv ðiz fulz u wɝk əɡɛns ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd!" tʃɛzməl weɪld.

"We have killed many of these fools who work against the Great Lord!" Chesmal wailed.

ɪleɪn wɪnst, ðɛn, stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf, kɹieɪɾəd ə wɪp ʌv ɛɹ ən læʃt ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə wʊmənz bæk. ɪt wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən tʃɛzməl dɪzɝvd. "ju?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "ju hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðɛɹ dɛθs! dʒju θɪŋk mi stupəd? dʒju θɪŋk mi ɪɡnɝənt!"

Elayne winced, then, steeling herself, created a whip of Air and lashed it across the woman's back. It was no more than Chesmal deserved. "You?" Elayne said. "You had nothing to do with their deaths! Do you think me stupid? Do you think me ignorant!"

"noʊ, ɡɹeɪt wʌn," tʃɛzməl weɪld, kɝlɪŋ ʌp fɝðɝ. "pliz!"

"No, Great One," Chesmal wailed, curling up further. "Please!"

"ðɛn ɡɪmi ɹizən tə lɛt jə lɪv."

"Then give me reason to let you live."

"aɪ hæv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ɡɹeɪt wʌn," tʃɛzməl sɛd kwɪkli. "wʌn ə ðoʊz wi wɝ toʊl tə sik, ðə tu mɛn ðət mʌs bi kɪld əɾ ɔl kɑsts . . . wʌn ɪz hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn!"

"I have information, Great One," Chesmal said quickly. "One of those we were told to seek, the two men that must be killed at all costs . . . one is here in Caemlyn!"

wʌts ðɪs? ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "tɛl mi mɔɹ."

What's this? Elayne hesitated. "Tell me more."

"hi ɹaɪdz wɪð ə mɝsənɛɹi ɡɹup," tʃɛzməl sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɹɪliv tə hæv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðət wɑz wɑntəd. "hi ɪz ðə mæn wɪð ðə kin aɪz u wɛɹz ðə hæɾ ən kæɹiz ðə spɪɹ mɑɹk baɪ ɹeɪvənz!"

"He rides with a mercenary group," Chesmal said, sounding relieved to have information that was wanted. "He is the man with the keen eyes who wears the hat and carries the spear marked by ravens!"

mæt? ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ hʌntɪŋ mæt? hi wɑz fɹɛnz wɪð ɹænd, tʃɹu, ən tɑvɝən. bʌt wʌt hæd mæt dʌn tə ɡeɪn ði aɪɹ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ðɛmsɛlvz? mɔɹ dɪstɝbɪŋ wɑz ðət tʃɛzməl nu ʌv mæts pɹɛzəns ɪn ðə sɪɾi. hi hædn ɝaɪvd əntɪl æftɝ ðə blæk sɪstɝz hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd! ðət mɛnt. . . .

Mat? The Darkfriends were hunting Mat? He was friends with Rand, true, and ta'veren. But what had Mat done to gain the ire of the Forsaken themselves? More disturbing was that Chesmal knew of Mat's presence in the city. He hadn't arrived until after the Black sisters had been captured! That meant. . . .

ðət mɛn tʃɛzməl ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɪn kɑntækt wɪð ʌðɝ dɑɹk-fɹɛnz. bʌt hu? "æn haʊ dɪd jə dɪskʌvɝ ðɪs? waɪ wɑz ðɪs nɑt ɹipɔɹɾəd ɝliɝ?"

That meant Chesmal and the others were in contact with other Dark-friends. But who? "And how did you discover this? Why was this not reported earlier?"

"aɪ ɡɑt nuz ðɪs vɛɹi deɪ, ɡɹeɪt wʌn," tʃɛzməl sɛd, saʊndɪŋ mɔɹ sɛlf-əʃʊɹd naʊ. "wi ɑɹ plænɪŋ ən əsæsəneɪʃən."

"I got news this very day, Great One," Chesmal said, sounding more self-assured now. "We are planning an assassination."

"æn haʊ kən jə də ðət waɪl ɪmpɹɪzənd?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd.

"And how can you do that while imprisoned?" Elayne demanded.

tʃɛzməl lʊkt ʌp bɹifli, hɝ skwɛɹ feɪs ʃoʊɪŋ kənfjuʒən. ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Chesmal looked up briefly, her square face showing confusion. She said nothing.

aɪv tɪpt əɹ ɔf ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ ʃʊd. ɪleɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ bɪhaɪn əɹ mæsk ə ʃædoʊz.

I've tipped her off that I don't know as much as I should. Elayne gritted her teeth behind her mask of shadows.

"ɡɹeɪt wʌn," tʃɛzməl sɛd. "aɪ hæv bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ maɪ ɔɹɾɝz kɛɹfəli. wəɹ ɔlmoʊst ɪn ə pəzɪʃən tə bɪɡɪn ði ɪnveɪʒən, əz kəmændəd. sun, ændɝ wɪl bi əwɑʃ wɪð ðə blʌɾ ʌv əɹ ɛnəmiz ən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ʃæl ɹeɪn ɪn faɪɝ ən æʃ.

"Great One," Chesmal said. "I have been following my orders carefully. We are almost in a position to begin the invasion, as commanded. Soon, Andor will be awash with the blood of our enemies and the Great Lord shall reign in fire and ash.

wɪl si ɪt dʌn."

We will see it done."

wʌt wɑz ðɪs? ən ɪnveɪʒən, ʌv ændɝ? ɪmpɑsəbəl! haʊ wəɾ ɪt hæp-pɛn? haʊ kəɾ ɪt hæpən? ən jɛt, dɛɹd ʃi æsk ðə kwɛstʃənz? tʃɛzməl sim tə səspɛk ðət sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ.

What was this? An invasion, of Andor? Impossible! How would it hap-pen? How could it happen? And yet, dared she ask the questions? Chesmal seemed to suspect that something was wrong.

"ju ɑɹ nɑt ðə tʃoʊzən u vɪzəɾəd mi bɪfɔɹ, ɑɹ ju, ɡɹeɪt wʌn?" tʃɛzməl æskt.

"You are not the Chosen who visited me before, are you, Great One?" Chesmal asked.

"aʊɝ weɪz ɑɹ nɑt tə bi kwɛstʃən baɪ wʌn sətʃ əz ju," ɪleɪn ɡɹaʊld, pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹɪmɑɹk wɪð ənʌðɝ swɪtʃ ʌv ɛɹ əkɹɔs ðə wʊmənz bæk. "aɪ nid tə noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ juv bɪn toʊld.

"Our ways are not to be questioned by one such as you," Elayne growled, punctuating the remark with another switch of Air across the woman's back. "I need to know how much you have been told.

soʊ ðəɾ aɪ kən dʒʌdʒ ðə ɡæps ɪn jəɹ ʌndɝstændɪŋ. ɪf jə ɑɹ ɪɡnɝən ʌv. . . . wɛl, ðəɾ ɪz tə bi sin.

So that I can judge the gaps in your understanding. If you are ignorant of. . . . Well, that is to be seen.

fɝst, ɪkspleɪn tə mi haʊ mʌtʃ jə noʊ ʌv ði ɪnveɪʒən."

First, explain to me how much you know of the invasion."

"aɪ noʊ ðət ðə dɛdlaɪn nɪɹz, ɡɹeɪt wʌn," tʃɛzməl sɛd. "ɪf wi hæd lɔŋɡɝ, pɝhæps wi kəd plæn mɔɹ ɪkstɛnsɪvli. ɪf jə kəd si mi fɹid fɹəm ðiz kɑnfaɪnz, ðən aɪ kəd . . ."

"I know that the deadline nears, Great One," Chesmal said. "If we had longer, perhaps we could plan more extensively. If you could see me freed from these confines, then I could . . ."

ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saɪd.

She trailed off, glancing to the side.

dɛdlaɪn. ɪleɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə dɪmæn mɔɹ, bʌt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. wʌt? ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fil ðə kɪn aʊtsaɪd. hæd ðeɪ ɹitʃɹiɾəd? ən wʌɾ ə tʃɛzməlz ʃild?

Deadline. Elayne opened her mouth to demand more, but hesitated. What? She could no longer feel the Kin outside. Had they retreated? And what of Chesmal's shield?

ðə dɔɹ ɹæɾəld, ðə lɑk spʌn, ðən ðə dɔɹ flu oʊpən, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə ɡɹup ə pipəl ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ðə ɡɹup ʌv ɡɑɹdz ɪleɪn hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ. ət ðɛɹ hɛd wɑz ə mæn wɪð ʃɔɹt blæk hɛɹ, θɪnɪŋ ət ðə saɪdz, ən hjudʒ mʌstæʃɪz. hi wɔɹ bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə blæk ʃɝt, hɪz koʊt lɔŋ, ɔlmoʊst ən oʊpən-fɹʌntɪd ɹoʊb.

The door rattled, the lock spun, then the door flew open, revealing a group of people on the other side. And they were not the group of Guards Elayne had been expecting. At their head was a man with short black hair, thinning at the sides, and huge mustaches. He wore brown trousers and a black shirt, his coat long, almost an open-fronted robe.

sɪlveɪsəz sɛkɹətɛɹi! bɪhaɪn ɪm wɝ tu wɪmən. təmeɪl ən ɛlʒɹɪθ. boʊθ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ.

Sylvase's secretary! Behind him were two women. Temaile and Eldrith. Both of the Black Ajah.

boʊθ hoʊldɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹs. laɪt!

Both holding to the Source. Light!

ɪleɪn staɪfəld əɹ sɝpɹaɪz, miɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡeɪz ən nɑt ɡɪvɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. ɪf ʃi kəd kənvɪns wʌn blæk sɪstɝ ðət ʃi wɑz ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ðən pɝhæps ʃi kəd kənvɪns θɹi. təmeɪlz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən ʃi θɹu hɝsɛlf tə hɝ niz, əz dɪd ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi. ɛlʒɹɪθ, haʊɛvɝ, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Elayne stifled her surprise, meeting their gaze and not giving ground. If she could convince one Black sister that she was of the Forsaken, then perhaps she could convince three. Temaile's eyes opened wide, and she threw herself to her knees, as did the secretary. Eldrith, however, hesitated.

ɪleɪn kʊdn bi sɝɾən ɪf ɪt wɑz əɹ stæns, hɝ dɪsɡaɪz, əɹ əɹ ɹiækʃən tə siɪŋ ðə θɹi nukʌmɝz. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli. iðɝ weɪ, ɛldɪɹɪθ wɑzn teɪkən ɪn. ðə ɹaʊnd- feɪst wʊmən bɪɡæn tə tʃænəl.

Elayne couldn't be certain if it was her stance, her disguise, or her reaction to seeing the three newcomers. Perhaps it was something else entirely. Either way, Eldirith wasn't taken in. The round- faced woman began to channel.

ɪleɪn kɝs tə hɝsɛlf, fɔɹmɪŋ wivz ə hɝ oʊn. ʃi slæmd ə ʃild əɾ ɛlʒɹɪθ ɹaɪɾ əz ʃi fɛlt wʌn kʌm fəɹ hɝ. fɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ mæts tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ðə wiv ənɹævəld, ən ðə mədæljən ɡɹu koʊld ɪn ɪleɪnz hænd. ɪleɪnz oʊn wiv slɪɾ ivənli bɪtwin ɛlʒɹɪθ ən ðə sɔɹs, kʌɾɪŋ əɹ ɔf. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ wɪŋkt aʊɾ ɝaʊn hɝ.

Elayne cursed to herself, forming weaves of her own. She slammed a shield at Eldrith right as she felt one come for her. Fortunately, she was holding Mat's ter'angreal. The weave unraveled, and the medallion grew cold in Elayne's hand. Elayne's own weave slid evenly between Eldrith and the Source, cutting her off. The glow of the Power winked out around her.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ, jə ɪɾiət!" tʃɛzməl skɹitʃt. "ju tʃɹaɪ tə oʊvɝ-θɹoʊ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən?

"What are you doing, you idiot!" Chesmal screeched. "You try to over-throw one of the Chosen?

jəl si əs ɔl dɛd!"

You'll see us all dead!"

"ðæts nɑt wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən," ɛlʒɹɪθ jɛl bæk. ɪleɪn bɪleɪɾədli θɔt tə wiv ə ɡæɡ ʌv ɛɹ. "juv bɪn dupt! ɪt - "

"That's not one of the Chosen," Eldrith yelled back. Elayne belatedly thought to weave a gag of Air. "You've been duped! It - "

ɪleɪn ɡɑt ðə ɡæɡ ɪn əɹ maʊθ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. təmeɪl - hu hæɾ ɔlweɪz lʊk tu dɛləkət tə bi ə blæk sɪstɝ - ɛmbɹeɪs ðə su ɹs ən lʊkt ʌp.

Elayne got the gag in her mouth, but it was too late. Temaile - who had always looked too delicate to be a Black sister - embraced the Sou rce and looked up.

tʃɛzməl ɛs ɪkspɹɛʃən tɝn fɹəm hɔɹɝ tə æŋɡɝ.

Chesmal s expression turned from horror to anger.

ɪleɪn kwɪkli taɪɾ ɔf ɛlʒɹɪθs ʃild ən bɪɡæn wivɪŋ ənʌðɝ wʌn ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ hɪt hɝ.

Elayne quickly tied off Eldrith's shield and began weaving another one A weave of Air hit her.

ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən ɡɹu koʊld, ən - blɛsɪŋ mæt fəɹ ɪz taɪmli loʊn - ɪleɪn pleɪst ə ʃil bɪtwin tʃɛzməl ən ðə sɔɹs.

The foxhead medallion grew cold, and - blessing Mat for his timely loan - Elayne placed a shield between Chesmal and the Source.

təmeɪl ɡeɪpt əɾ ɪleɪn, ɑbviəsli stʌn tə si hɝ wivz feɪl. sɪl-veɪs ɛs sɛkɹətɛɹi wɑzn soʊ sloʊ, haʊɛvɝ. hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf fɔɹwɝɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli, ɹæmɪŋ ɪleɪn bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə fɔɹs.

Temaile gaped at Elayne, obviously stunned to see her weaves fail. Syl-vase s secretary wasn't so slow, however. He threw himself forward unexpectedly, ramming Elayne back against the wall with a great deal of force.

peɪn leɪst aʊt fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən ʃi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ kɹæk. hɝ ʃoʊldɝ boʊn? ðə beɪbz!

Pain laced out from her shoulder, and she felt something crack. Her shoulder bone? The babes!

ʃi θɔɾ ɪmiɾiətli. ɪt wɑz ə pɹaɪməl flæʃ ə hɔɹɝ ən ɪnstən tɛɹɝ ðət dɪfaɪɾ ɔl θɔts əbaʊt mɪn ən vjuɪŋz. ɪn əɹ sɝpɹaɪz, ʃi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə ɡeɪtweɪ liɾɪŋ bæk tə hɝ ɹum əbʌv. ɪt wɪŋkt aʊt.

she thought immediately. It was a primal flash of horror and instant terror that defied all thoughts about Min and viewings. In her surprise, she let go of the gateway leading back to her room above. It winked out.

"ʃi hæz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹiaɪ ɑsoʊm kaɪnd," təmeɪl kɹaɪd. "wivz fɔl ɔf hɝ."

"She has a ter'angreai osome kind," Temaile cried. "Weaves fall off her."

ɪleɪn skɹæmbəld, pʊʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ tə θɹʌst ɪm bæk.

Elayne scrambled, pushing against the secretary and beginning a weave of Air to thrust him back.

əz ʃi dɪd, haʊɛvɝ, hi klɔɾ əɾ əɹ hænd, pɝhæps hævɪŋ noʊɾəst ə flæʃ ə sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl ðɛɹ.

As she did, however, he clawed at her hand, perhaps having noticed a flash of silvery metal there.

ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi ɡɑɾ ɪz lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝz ɝaʊn ðə mədæljən dʒʌst əz ɪleɪnz bɝst ʌv ɛɹ hɪt hɪm.

The secretary got his long fingers around the medallion just as Elayne's burst of Air hit him.

ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi flu bækwɝd, klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə mədæljən. ɪleɪn ɡɹaʊld, stɪl fjʊɹiəs. təmeɪl ɡɹɪn məlɪʃɪsli, ən wivz ʌv ɛɹ spɹæŋ ʌp ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi θɹu ðɛm fɔɹwɝd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn mɛɾ əm wɪð əɹ oʊn.

The secretary flew backward, clinging to the medallion. Elayne growled, still furious. Temaile grinned maliciously, and weaves of Air sprang up around her. She threw them forward, but Elayne met them with her own.

ðə tu wivz ʌv ɛɹ slæmd əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ, kɑzɪŋ ði ɛɹ tə tʃɝn ɪn ðə smɔl ɹum.

The two weaves of Air slammed against one another, causing the air to churn in the small room.

bɪts ə stʃɹɔ blu ʌp ɪn ə flɝi. ɪleɪnz ɪɹz pɹətɛstəd ðə sʌɾən pɹɛʃɝ. ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd sɛkɹətɛɹi skɹæmbəl bæk fɹəm ðə bæɾəl, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹiaɪ. ɪleɪn ɹitʃt ə wiv təwɔɹɾ ɪm - bʌɾ ɪɾ ənɹævəld.

Bits of straw blew up in a flurry. Elayne's ears protested the sudden pressure. The dark-haired secretary scrambled back from the battle, clutching the ter'angreai. Elayne reached a weave toward him - but it unraveled.

ɪleɪn jɛld ɪn æŋɡɝ, peɪn θɹɑbɪŋ ɪn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ wɛɹ ʃid hɪt ðə wɔl. ðə smɔl ɹum wɑz kɹæmpt wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl ɪn ɪt, ən təmeɪl stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ʌnɪntɛnʃənəli blɑkɪŋ ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɪntɛnʃənəl; ʃi pɹɑbli wɑntəd ðət mədæljən.

Elayne yelled in anger, pain throbbing in her shoulder where she'd hit the wall. The small room was cramped with so many people in it, and Temaile stood in the doorway, unintentionally blocking the secretary from getting away. Or maybe it was intentional; she probably wanted that medallion.

ði ʌðɝ tu blæk sɪstɝz hʌŋkɝd daʊn, ɛɹ blæstɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm, stɪl ʃildɪd.

The other two Black sisters hunkered down, air blasting around them, still shielded.

ɪleɪn dʒɹu əz mʌtʃ θɹu ði æŋɡɹil əz ʃi dɛɹd, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ wiv ʌv ɛɹ fɔɹwɝd, ʃʌvɪŋ əsaɪd ðə wʌn təmeɪl wɑz juzɪŋ tə pʊʃ. ðə tu hɛl fəɹ ə moʊmənt; ðən ɪleɪnz bɝs θɹu, kɹæʃɪŋ ɪndə təmeɪl ən tɔsɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə sɛl ən əɡɛns ðə stoʊn wɔl aʊtsaɪd. ɪleɪn fɑloʊd wɪð ə ʃild, ðoʊ ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət təmeɪl hæd bɪn nɑkt ʌnkɑnʃəs baɪ ðə blæst. ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi boʊltəd fəɹ ðə nɪɹbaɪ dɔɹweɪ. ɪleɪn fɛlt ə stæb ə pænɪk, ʃi dɪd ði oʊnli θɪŋ ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv. ʃi pɪkt ʌp tʃɛzməl ɪn ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ ən θɹu hɝ ət ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi.

Elayne drew as much through the angreal as she dared, forcing her weave of Air forward, shoving aside the one Temaile was using to push. The two held for a moment; then Elayne's burst through, crashing into Temaile and tossing her out of the cell and against the stone wall outside. Elayne followed with a shield, though it appeared that Temaile had been knocked unconscious by the blast. The secretary bolted for the nearby doorway. Elayne felt a stab of panic, She did the only thing she could think of. She picked up Chesmal in a weave of Air and threw her at the secretary.

boʊθ wɛn daʊn ɪn ə hip. ə mətælɪk pɪŋ saʊndəɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ əz ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən slɪp fɹi ən hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ðə dɔɹ.

Both went down in a heap. A metallic ping sounded in the air as the foxhead medallion slipped free and hit the ground, rolling through the door.

ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, peɪn flɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst, hɝ ɑɹm fɔlɪŋ slæk. ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hoʊld ɪɾ ʌp pɹɑpɝli. ʃi kɹæɾəld ɪɾ ɪn əɹ ʌðɝ ɑɹm, æŋɡɹi, klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹs. ðə switnəs ə seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz ə kʌmfɝt.

Elayne took a deep breath, pain flaring across her chest, her arm falling slack. She could no longer hold it up properly. She cradled it in her other arm, angry, clinging to the Source. The sweetness of saidar was a comfort.

ʃi woʊv ɛɹ ən taɪɾ ʌp tʃɛzməl, ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi ən ɛlʒɹɪθ, hu hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɹɔl təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn ʌnəbtʃɹusɪvli.

She wove Air and tied up Chesmal, the secretary and Eldrith, who had been trying to crawl toward Elayne unobtrusively.

kɑmɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn pʊʃt pæst əm aʊɾ ə ðə smɔl sɛl tə tʃɛk ɑn təmeɪl ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd. ðə wʊmən wɑz stɪl bɹiðɪŋ, bʌt wɑz ɪndiɾ ʌnkɑnʃəs. ɪleɪn taɪɾ əɹ ɪn ɛɹ, tu, tə bi sɝɾən, ðən kɛɹfəli pɪkt ʌp ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən. ʃi wɪnst ət ðə peɪn ə hɝ ʌðɝ ɑɹm.

Calming herself, Elayne pushed past them out of the small cell to check on Temaile in the hallway outside. The woman was still breathing, but was indeed unconscious. Elayne tied her in Air, too, to be certain, then carefully picked up the foxhead medallion. She winced at the pain of her other arm.

jɛs, ʃid bɹoʊkən ə boʊn fəɹ sɝɾən.

Yes, she'd broken a bone for certain.

ðə dɑɹk hɔlweɪ wɑz ɛmpti, sɛt wɪð fɔɹ dɔɹweɪz fəɹ sɛlz, lɪt baɪ oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl stænd-læmp.

The dark hallway was empty, set with four doorways for cells, lit by only a single stand-lamp.

wɛɹ wɝ ðə ɡɑɹdz ən kɪn? ʃi ɹɪlʌktənli ɹilis ðə wivz ðət fɔɹmd əɹ dɪsɡaɪz - ʃi wʊdnt wɑn ɛni soʊlʒɝz ɝaɪvɪŋ ən mɪsteɪkɪŋ əɹ fəɹ wʌn ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz. sɝɾənli sʌmwʌn hæd hɝd səm ə ðət ɹækɪt! ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd, ʃi kəd sɛns kənsɝn fɹəm bɝdʒɪt, hu wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊsɝ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæɾ əndaʊɾɪdli fɛlt ɪleɪnz ɪnʒɝi.

Where were the Guards and Kin? She reluctantly released the weaves that formed her disguise - she wouldn't want any soldiers arriving and mistaking her for one of the Darkfriends. Certainly someone had heard some of that racket! In the back of her mind, she could sense concern from Birgitte, who was getting closer. The Warder had undoubtedly felt Elayne's injury.

ɔlmoʊst, ɪleɪn pɹəfɝd ðə peɪn ə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ tə ðə lɛktʃɝ ʃid ɡɛt fɹəm bɝdʒɪt. ʃi wɪnst əɡɛn, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðæt, əz ʃi tɝn ən ɪnspɛktɪɾ əɹ kæptɪvz. ʃid nid tə tʃɛk ði ʌðɝ sɛlz.

Almost, Elayne preferred the pain of her shoulder to the lecture she'd get from Birgitte. She winced again, considering that, as she turned and inspected her captives. She'd need to check the other cells.

ʌv kɔɹs əɹ beɪbz wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪt. ʃi wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪt. ʃiɾ oʊvɝɹiæktɪd tə ðə peɪn; ʃi hædn ɹɪli bɪn əfɹeɪd. stɪl, bɛs tə -  həloʊ, maɪ kwin," ə mænz vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn əɹ ɪɹ ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ə sɛkən peɪn blɑsəmd ɪn əɹ saɪd. ʃi ɡæspt, stʌmbəlɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ə hæn ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən jæŋk ðə mədæljən fɹəm əɹ fɪŋɡɝz.

Of course her babes would be all right. She would be all right. She'd overreacted to the pain; she hadn't really been afraid. Still, best to -  Hello, my Queen," a man's voice whispered in her ear right before a second pain blossomed in her side. She gasped, stumbling forward. A hand reached out and yanked the medallion from her fingers.

ɪleɪn spʌn, ən ðə ɹum sim blɝi. sʌmθɪŋ wɔɹm ɹæn daʊn əɹ saɪd. ʃi wɑz bliɾɪŋ!

Elayne spun, and the room seemed blurry. Something warm ran down her side. She was bleeding!

ʃi wɑz soʊ stʌnd, ʃi fɛl ðə sɔɹs slɪp əweɪ fɹəm hɝ.

She was so stunned, she felt the Source slip away from her.

dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ stʊd bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, hoʊldɪŋ ə blʌɾid naɪf ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, hɛftɪŋ ðə mədæljən ɪn ɪz lɛft. hɪz hætʃətlaɪk feɪs wɑz bɹoʊkən baɪ ə dip smaɪl, ɔlmoʊst ə lɪɹ. ðoʊ hi wɔɹ oʊnli ɹæɡz, hi lʊkt əz sɛlf-əʃʊɹɾ əz ə kɪŋ ɑn ɪz θɹoʊn.

Doilin Mellar stood behind her in the hallway, holding a bloodied knife in his right hand, hefting the medallion in his left. His hatchetlike face was broken by a deep smile, almost a leer. Though he wore only rags, he looked as self-assured as a king on his throne.

ɪleɪn hɪst ən ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs. bʌt nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. ʃi hɝd tʃʌklɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Elayne hissed and reached for the Source. But nothing happened. She heard chuckling behind her.

ʃid hædn taɪɾ ɔf tʃɛzməlz ʃild! əz sun əz ɪleɪn ɹilis ðə sɔɹs, ɹə wivz wəɾ əv vænɪʃt. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, ɪleɪn ɡlænst ən faʊnd wivz kʌɾɪŋ əɹ ɔf fɹəm ðə sɔɹs.

She'd hadn't tied off Chesmal's shield! As soon as Elayne released the Source, rhe weaves would have vanished. Sure enough, Elayne glanced and found weaves cutting her off from the Source.

tʃɛzməl, hænsəm feɪs flʌʃt, smaɪld ət hɝ. laɪt! ðəɹ wɑz blʌd pulɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪnz fit.

Chesmal, handsome face flushed, smiled at her. Light! There was blood pooling at Elayne's feet.

soʊ mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt.

So much of it.

ʃi stʌmbəl bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl ə ðə hɔlweɪ, mɛlɝ tə wʌn saɪd, tʃɛzməl ði ʌðɝ.

She stumbled back against the wall of the hallway, Mellar to one side, Chesmal the other.

ʃi kʊdn daɪ. mɪn hæd sɛd . . . wi kəd bi mɪsɪntɝpɹəɾɪŋ. bɝdʒɝts vɔɪs ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ.

She couldn't die. Min had said . . . We could be misinterpreting. Birgirte's voice returned to her.

ɛni nʌmbɝ ə θɪŋz kəd stɪl ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ.

Any number of things could still go wrong.

"hil hɝ," mɛlɝ sɛd.

"Heal her," Mellar said.

"wʌt?" tʃɛzməl dɪmændəd. bɪhaɪn hɝ, ɛlʒɹɪθ wɑz dʌstɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɔf ɪnsaɪd ðə sɛl dɔɹweɪ.

"What?" Chesmal demanded. Behind her, Eldrith was dusting herself off inside the cell doorway.

ʃid fɔlən tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wən ɪleɪnz wiv-ɪŋz ʌv ɛɹ dɪsəpeɪɾɪd, bʌɾ əɹ ʃild wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ.

She'd fallen to the ground when Elayne's weav-ings of Air dissipated, but her shield was still there.

ðət wʌn ɪleɪn hæd taɪɾ ɪn pleɪs.

That one Elayne had tied in place.

θɪŋk, ɪleɪn toʊl hɝsɛlf, blʌd dʒɹɪbəlɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ðəɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ aʊt. ðəɹ əz tə bi! oʊ, laɪt! bɝdʒɪt, hɝi!

Think, Elayne told herself, blood dribbling between her fingers. There has to be a way out. There has to be! Oh, Light! Birgitte, hurry!

"hil hɝ," mɛlɝ sɛɾ əɡɛn. "ðə naɪf waʊnd wɑz tə meɪk əɹ dʒɹɑp ju."

"Heal her," Mellar said again. "The knife wound was to make her drop you."

"ful," tʃɛzməl sɛd. "ɪf ðə wivz hæd bɪn taɪɾ ɔf, ə waʊnd wʊdn əv ɹilist ʌs!"

"Fool," Chesmal said. "If the weaves had been tied off, a wound wouldn't have released us!"

"ðɛn ʃi wəɾ əv daɪd," mɛlɝ sɛd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ. hi aɪɾ ɪleɪn; ðoʊz hænsəm aɪz ə hɪz ʃoʊn wɪð lʌst. "æn ðət wʊɾə bɪn ə pɪɾi. fəɹ ʃi wɑz pɹɑməs tə mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ woʊn əv əɹ daɪ hɪɹ ɪn ðɪs dʌnʒən. ʃi dʌzn daɪ əntɪl aɪ hæv hæd taɪm tə . . . ɛndʒɔɪ hɝ." hi lʊkt ət ðə blæk sɪstɝ. "bɪsaɪdz, jə θɪŋk ðoʊz hum wi sɝv wəd bi plizd ɪf ðeɪ nu jud lɛt ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ daɪ wɪθaʊt jildɪŋ əɹ sikɹəts?"

"Then she would have died," Mellar said, shrugging. He eyed Elayne; those handsome eyes of his shone with lust. "And that would have been a pity. For she was promised to me, Aes Sedai. I won't have her die here in this dungeon. She doesn't die until I have had time to . . . enjoy her." He looked at the Black sister. "Besides, you think those whom we serve would be pleased if they knew you'd let the Queen of Andor die without yielding her secrets?"

tʃɛzməl lʊk dɪsæɾəsfaɪd, bʌt ʃi əpɛɹənli sɔ ðə wɪzdəm ɪn ɪz wɝdz. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi slɪpt aʊɾ ə ðə sɛl ən - æftɝ ɡlænsɪŋ boʊθ weɪz - slʌŋk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ təwɔɹd ðə stɛps ən hɝiɾ ʌp ðɛm. tʃɛzməl kɹɔs ðə hɔlweɪ təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn. blɛsədli. ɪleɪn wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ fʌzi-hɛɾəd. ʃi ɹɛstəɾ əɹ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, bɛɹli filɪŋ ðə peɪn ə hɝ bɹoʊkən ʃoʊldɝ, ən slɪd daʊn əntɪl ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ.

Chesmal looked dissatisfied, but she apparently saw the wisdom in his words. Behind them, the secretary slipped out of the cell and - after glancing both ways - slunk down the hallway toward the steps and hurried up them. Chesmal crossed the hallway toward Elayne. Blessedly. Elayne was getting fuzzy-headed. She rested her back against the wall, barely feeling the pain of her broken shoulder, and slid down until she was sitting.

"ɪɾiət ɡɝl," tʃɛzməl sɛd. "aɪ sɔ θɹu jəɹ plɔɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. aɪ wɑz liɾɪŋ jə ɑn, noʊɪŋ ðət hɛlp wɑz kʌmɪŋ."

"Idiot girl," Chesmal said. "I saw through your ploy, of course. I was leading you on, knowing that help was coming."

ðə wɝdz wɝ hɑloʊ; ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ fəɹ ðə bɛnəfɪɾ ə ði ʌðɝz. ðə hilɪŋ. ɪleɪn niɾəd .

The words were hollow; she was lying for the benefit of the others. The Healing. Elayne needed .

. . ðət . . . hilɪŋ. hɝ maɪnd wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dʌl, hɝ vɪʒən dɑɹkənɪŋ. ʃi hɛld əɹ hæn tə hɝ saɪd, tɛɹəfaɪd fəɹ hɝsɛlf, fəɹ əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən.

. . that . . . Healing. Her mind was growing dull, her vision darkening. She held her hand to her side, terrified for herself, for her children.

hɝ hæn slɪpt. ʃi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ θɹu ðə fæbɹɪk ɪn ðə pɑkəɾ ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən kɑpi.

Her hand slipped. She felt something through the fabric in the pocket of her dress. The foxhead medallion copy.

tʃɛzməl pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ɪleɪnz hɛd, kɹæftɪŋ hilɪŋ wivz. ɪleɪnz veɪnz bɪkeɪm aɪs wɔɾɝ, hɝ bɑɾi oʊvɝwɛlm baɪ ə weɪv ə paʊɝ. ʃi dʒɹu ɪn ə dip bɹɛθ, ði æɡəni ɪn əɹ saɪɾ ən ʃoʊldɝ vænɪʃɪŋ.

Chesmal put her hands on Elayne's head, crafting Healing weaves. Elayne's veins became ice water, her body overwhelmed by a wave of Power. She drew in a deep breath, the agony in her side and shoulder vanishing.

"ðɛɹ," tʃɛzməl sɛd. "naʊ, kwɪkli, wi nid tə - "

"There," Chesmal said. "Now, quickly, we need to - "

ɪleɪn wɪp fɹi ði ʌðɝ mədæljən ən hɛld ɪɾ ʌp. baɪ ɹiflɛks, tʃɛzməl ɡɹæbd ɪt. ðət meɪd ðə wʊmən əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl. hɝ wivz vænɪʃt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz ʃild.

Elayne whipped free the other medallion and held it up. By reflex, Chesmal grabbed it. That made the woman unable to channel. Her weaves vanished, including Elayne's shield.

tʃɛzməl kɝst, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə mədæljən. ɪt hɪɾ ən ɹoʊld əz tʃɛzməl woʊv ə ʃild.

Chesmal cursed, dropping the medallion. It hit and rolled as Chesmal wove a shield.

ɪleɪn dɪdn bɑðɝ wɪð ə ʃild. ðɪs taɪm, ʃi woʊv faɪɝ. sɪmpəl, dɝɛkt, deɪnʒɝəs. ðə dɑɹk sɪstɝz kloʊðɪŋ bɝst ɪndə fleɪm bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd fɪnɪʃ wivɪŋ, ən ʃi kɹaɪɾ aʊt.

Elayne didn't bother with a shield. This time, she wove Fire. Simple, direct, dangerous. The Dark sister's clothing burst into flame before she could finish weaving, and she cried out.

ɪleɪn hɔl hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit. ðə hɔlweɪ ʃʊk ən spʌn - ðə hilɪŋ hæd teɪkən ə lɑɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ - bʌt bɪfɔɹ θɪŋz stɑp spɪnɪŋ, ʃi woʊv ənʌðɝ θɹɛɾ ə faɪɝ, læʃɪŋ ɪɾ ət mɛlɝ. hi hæd ɹɪsk ðə laɪf ə hɝ tʃɪlʒɹən! hi hæd stæb hɝ! hi . . .

Elayne hauled herself to her feet. The hallway shook and spun - the Healing had taken a lot out of her - but before things stopped spinning, she wove another thread of Fire, lashing it at Mellar. He had risked the life of her children! He had stabbed her! He . . .

ðə wivz ənɹævəl ðə moʊmən ðeɪ tʌtʃt hɪm. hi smaɪld ʌp ət hɝ, stɑpɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ɪz fʊt. ðə sɛkən mədæljən. "hɪɹ naʊ," hi sɛd, skupɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp. "ənʌðɝ wʌn? ɪf aɪ ʃeɪk ju, wɪl ə θɝd fɔl fɹi?"

The weaves unraveled the moment they touched him. He smiled up at her, stopping something with his foot. The second medallion. "Here now," he said, scooping it up. "Another one? If I shake you, will a third fall free?"

ɪleɪn hɪst. tʃɛzməl wɑz stɪl skɹimɪŋ, əfaɪɹ. ʃi fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kɪkɪŋ, ðə hɔlweɪ ɡɹoʊɪŋ pʌnʒənt wɪð ðə sɛn ə bɝn flɛʃ. laɪt! ɪleɪn hædn mɛn tə kɪl hɝ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn taɪm tə spɛɹ. ʃi woʊv ɛɹ, snætʃɪŋ ʌp ɛlʒɹɪθ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən kəɾ ɪskeɪp. ɪleɪn pʊʃt əɹ fɔɹwɝd, bɪtwin hɝsɛlf ən mɛlɝ, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. hi wɑtʃt wɪð kin aɪz, ɛdʒɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə tu mədæljənz ɪn wʌn hæn ən ɪz dæɡɝ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. ɪt stɪl ɡlɪsənd wɪð ɪleɪnz blʌd. "wi ɑɹən fɪnɪʃt, maɪ kwin," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs. "ðiz ʌðɝz wɝ pɹɑməs paʊɝ. bʌt maɪ ɹɪwɔɹd wɑz ɔlweɪz tə bi ju. aɪ ɔlweɪz kʌlɛkt wʌɾ aɪm oʊd." hi wɑtʃt ɪleɪn wɪð kɛɹ, ɪkspɛktɪŋ səm tʃɹɪk.

Elayne hissed. Chesmal was still screaming, afire. She fell to the ground, kicking, the hallway growing pungent with the scent of burned flesh. Light! Elayne hadn't meant to kill her. But there wasn't time to spare. She wove Air, snatching up Eldrith again before the woman could escape. Elayne pushed her forward, between herself and Mellar, just in case. He watched with keen eyes, edging forward, holding the two medallions in one hand and his dagger in the other. It still glistened with Elayne's blood. "We aren't finished, my Queen," he said in a soft voice. "These others were promised power. But my reward was always to be you. I always collect what I am owed." He watched Elayne with care, expecting some trick.

ɪf oʊnli ʃi hæd wʌn! ʃi kəd bɛɹli stæn əpɹaɪt. hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹs wɑz dɪfəkəlt. ʃi bækt əweɪ, kipɪŋ ɛlʒɹɪθ bɪtwin hɝsɛlf ən mɛlɝ. hɪz aɪz flɪk tə ðə stætʃuɛsk wʊmən; ʃi stʊd wɪð ɑɹmz taɪd tə hɝ saɪdz baɪ ɛɹ, floʊɾɪŋ ən ɪntʃ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. wɪð ə dʒɝkɪŋ moʊʃən, hi dʒʌmp fɔɹwɝɾ ən slɪɾ ɛlʒɹɪθs θɹoʊt. ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd, skɹæmbəlɪŋ bækwɝd.

If only she had one! She could barely stand upright. Holding the Source was difficult. She backed away, keeping Eldrith between herself and Mellar. His eyes flicked to the statuesque woman; she stood with arms tied to her sides by Air, floating an inch above the ground. With a jerking motion, he jumped forward and slit Eldrith's throat. Elayne started, scrambling backward.

"sɑɹi," mɛlɝ sɛd, ən ɪt tʊk ɪleɪn ə moʊmən tə ɹilaɪz i wɑz æd-dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɛlʒɹɪθ. "bʌɾ ɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ ɔɹɾɝz." wɪð ðæt, hi dʌkt, plʌnʒɪŋ ɪz dæɡɝ ɪndə təmeɪlz ʌnkɑnʃəs bɑɾi.

"Sorry," Mellar said, and it took Elayne a moment to realize he was ad-dressing Eldrith. "But orders are orders." With that, he ducked, plunging his dagger into Temaile's unconscious body.

hi kʊdn ɪskeɪp wɪð ðə mədæljənz! wɪð ə sɝdʒ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ, ɪleɪn dʒɹu ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən woʊv ɝθ. ʃi pʊld ət ðə silɪŋ əbʌv mɛlɝ əz i stʊɾ ʌp. stoʊnz ʃæɾɝd, blɑks fɔlɪŋ daʊnwɝd, kɑzɪŋ ɪm tə jɛl ən kʌvɝ ɪz hɛɾ əz i dʌkt əweɪ. sʌmθɪŋ ɹæŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. mɛɾəl ɑn stoʊn.

He couldn't escape with the medallions! With a surge of strength, Elayne drew in the One Power and wove Earth. She pulled at the ceiling above Mellar as he stood up. Stones shattered, blocks falling downward, causing him to yell and cover his head as he ducked away. Something rang in the air. Metal on stone.

ðə hɔlweɪ ʃʊk, ən dʌst spɹeɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ. ðə ɹeɪn ə ɹɑks dʒɹoʊv mɛlɝ əweɪ, bʌt kɛpt əɹ fɹəm tʃeɪsɪŋ. hi vænɪʃt ʌp ðə stɛɹwɛl tə ðə ɹaɪt. ɪleɪn sæŋk daʊn tə hɝ niz, filɪŋ dʒɹeɪnd. bʌt ðən ʃi sɔ sʌmθɪŋ ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ɹʌbəl ə ðə silɪŋ blɑks ʃid pʊl daʊn. ə bɪɾ ə sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl. wʌn ə ðə mədæljənz.

The hallway shook, and dust sprayed in the air. The rain of rocks drove Mellar away, but kept her from chasing. He vanished up the stairwell to the right. Elayne sank down to her knees, feeling drained. But then she saw something glittering among the rubble of the ceiling blocks she'd pulled down. A bit of silvery metal. One of the medallions.

hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi ɡɹæbd ɪt. blɛsədli, ðə sɔɹs dɪdn liv hɝ. mɛlɝ hæɾ ɪskeɪpt wɪð ðə kɑpi, ɪt simd, bʌt ʃi stɪl hæd ði ɝɪdʒənəl.

Holding her breath, she grabbed it. Blessedly, the Source didn't leave her. Mellar had escaped with the copy, it seemed, but she still had the original.

ʃi saɪd, əlaʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə sɪt bæk əɡɛns ðə koʊl stoʊn wɔl. ʃi wɑntəd tə læps ɪndə ʌnkɑnʃəsnəs, bʌt fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə tʌk əweɪ ðə mədæljən, ðən ɹɪmeɪn əweɪk əntɪl bɝdʒɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ pæntɪd hɛvəli fɹəm hævɪŋ ɹʌn, hɝ ɹɛd koʊɾ ən ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd wɛt wɪð ɹeɪnwɔɾɝ.

She sighed, allowing herself to sit back against the cold stone wall. She wanted to lapse into unconsciousness, but forced herself to tuck away the medallion, then remain awake until Birgitte appeared in the hallway. The Warder panted heavily from having run, her red coat and golden braid wet with rainwater.

mæt stɛp daʊn ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ æftɝ hɝ, wɛɹɪŋ ə skɑɹf ʌp ɝaʊn ɪz feɪs, hɪz wɛt bɹaʊn hɛɹ plæstɝd tə hɪz hɛd. hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd, ə kɔɹɾɝstæf hɛld ət ɡɑɹd.

Mat stepped down into the hallway after her, wearing a scarf up around his face, his wet brown hair plastered to his head. His eyes darted from side to side, a quarterstaff held at guard.

bɝdʒɪt nɛl baɪ ɪleɪnz saɪd. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" ʃi æskt ɝdʒənli.

Birgitte knelt by Elayne's side. "Are you all right?" she asked urgently.

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd ɪn ɪɡzɔstʃən. "aɪ ɡɑt maɪsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðɪs wʌn." ɪn ə weɪ. "dɪd jə hæpən tə də ðə wɝld ə feɪvɝ ən kɪl mɛlɝ ɑn jəɹ weɪ ɪn?"

Elayne nodded in exhaustion. "I got myself out of this one." In a way. "Did you happen to do the world a favor and kill Mellar on your way in?"

"mɛlɝ?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt, əlɑɹmd. "noʊ. ɪleɪn, ðɛɹz blʌɾ ɑn jəɹ dʒɹɛs!"

"Mellar?" Birgitte asked, alarmed. "No. Elayne, there's blood on your dress!"

"aɪm faɪn," ʃi sɛd. "ɹɪli, aɪv bɪn hild."

"I'm fine," she said. "Really, I've been Healed."

soʊ mɛlɝ wɑz fɹi. "kwɪkli," ʃi sɛd. "sɝtʃ ðə hɔlweɪz. ðə ɡɑɹdz ən ðə kɪn u wɝ ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðɪs pleɪs - "

So Mellar was free. "Quickly," she said. "Search the hallways. The Guards and the Kin who were guarding this place - "

"wi faʊn ðɛm," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "stʌft ɪndə ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stɛɹwɛl. dɛd. ɪleɪn, wʌt hæpənd?" tə ðə saɪd, mæt poʊkt ət təmeɪlz kɔɹps, noʊɾɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ waʊn ɪn əɹ tʃɛst.

"We found them," Birgitte said. "Stuffed into the bottom of the stairwell. Dead. Elayne, what happened?" To the side, Mat poked at Temailes corpse, noting the dagger wound in her chest.

ɪleɪn pɹɛst əɹ hænz tə hɝ æbdoʊmən. hɝ beɪbz wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪt, wʊdn ðeɪ? "aɪ dɪd sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi ɹæʃ, bɝdʒɪt, ən aɪ noʊ ðət jə ɑɹ gɑnə skɹim ət mi fəɹ ɪt. bʌt wəd jə fɝs pliz teɪk mi tə maɪ ɹumz? aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəɾ əv mɛlfən lʊk ət mi. dʒʌst ɪn keɪs."

Elayne pressed her hands to her abdomen. Her babes would be all right, wouldn't they? "I did something very rash, Birgitte, and I know that you are going to scream at me for it. But would you first please take me to my rooms? I think we should have Melfane look at me. Just in case."

* * * ən aʊɝ æftɝ ðə feɪld əsæsəneɪʃən ətɛmpt ɑn ɛɡwin, ɡɔɪn stʊɾ əloʊn ɪn ə smɔl ɹum ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ði æmɪɝlɪnz tʃeɪmbɝz. hid bɪn ɹilis fɹəm ðə wivz ðət hæd hɛl hɪm, ðən toʊl tə steɪ pʊt. ɛɡwin faɪnəli stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "sɪt," ʃi sɛd.

* * * An hour after the failed assassination attempt on Egwene, Gawyn stood alone in a small room that was part of the Amyrlin's chambers. He'd been released from the weaves that had held him, then told to stay put. Egwene finally strode into the room. "Sit," she said.

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌɾ əɹ fɪɹs aɪz cʊɾə sɛt kændəlz əfleɪm. hi sæt daʊn ɑn ðə stul. ðɪs smɔl ɹum hɛl sɛvɹəl dʒɹɛsɝz ən tʃɹʌŋks fəɹ kloʊðɪŋ. ðə dɔɹweɪ lɛɾ aʊt tə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɛɹ hid bɪn kæptʃɝɾ ɪn wivz; ə dɔɹweɪ ɔf ə ðət ɹum lɛd tə ɛɡwinz bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ.

He hesitated, but her fierce eyes could have set candles aflame. He sat down on the stool. This small room held several dressers and trunks for clothing. The doorway led out to the larger sitting room where he'd been captured in weaves; a doorway off of that room led to Egwene's bedchamber.

ɛɡwin ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ, sɪkwɛstɝɪŋ ðə tu ʌv əm fɹəm ðə mɛni ɡɑɹdz, wɔɹɾɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ mɪlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹumz aʊtsaɪd. ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃənz meɪɾ ə loʊ hʌm θɹu ðə dɔɹ. ɛɡwin stɪl wɔɹ ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld ən ʃi hæd ɡoʊldən θɹɛdz woʊvən ɪndə hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ. hɝ tʃiks wɝ flʌʃt wɪð æŋɡɝ ət hɪm. ðət meɪɾ əɹ ivən mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl ðən juʒəwəl.

Egwene shut the door, sequestering the two of them from the many guards, Warders and Aes Sedai milling about in the rooms outside. Their conversations made a low hum through the door. Egwene still wore red and gold and she had golden threads woven into her dark hair. Her cheeks were flushed with anger at him. That made her even more beautiful than usual.

"ɛɡwin, aɪ - "

"Egwene, I - "

"du jə ɹilaɪz wʌt juv dʌn?"

"Do you realize what you have done?"

"aɪ tʃɛk tə si ɪf ðə wʊmən aɪ lʌv wɑz seɪf, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə dɪskʌvɝi ʌv ən əsæsən aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ dɔɹ."
