"I checked to see if the woman I love was safe, following the discovery of an assassin outside her door."

ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə hiɾ ə hɝ æŋɡɝ. "jɔɹ jɛlɪŋ əz dʒɹɔn hæf ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðeɪ sɔ jə kæptʃɝd. ði əsæsən pɹɑbli noʊz, naʊ, əbaʊt maɪ wivz."

She folded her arms beneath her breasts. He could almost feel the heat of her anger. "Your yelling has drawn half of the White Tower. They saw you captured. The assassin probably knows, now, about my weaves."

"laɪt, ɛɡwin! jə tɔk əz ɪf aɪ dɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn pɝpəs. aɪ wɑz oʊnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹətɛk ju."

"Light, Egwene! You talk as if I did it on purpose. I was only trying to protect you."

"aɪ dɪdn æsk fəɹ jəɹ pɹətɛkʃən! aɪ æsk fəɹ jəɹ oʊbiɾiəns! ɡɔɪn, doʊn jə si ði ɑpɝtunəɾi wiv mɪst? ɪf jə hædn skɛɹd mɛsænə əweɪ, ʃiɾ əv wɔkt ɪndə maɪ tʃɹæps!"

"I didn't ask for your protection! I asked for your obedience! Gawyn, don't you see the opportunity we've missed? If you hadn't scared Mesaana away, she'd have walked into my traps!"

"ɪt wɑznt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ɪt wɑz ə mæn."

"It wasn't one of the Forsaken," Gawyn said. "It was a man."

"ju sɛd jə kʊdn si ðə feɪs əɹ meɪk aʊt ðə fɪɡjɝ kəz ɪt wɑz blɝd."

"You said you couldn't see the face or make out the figure because it was blurred."

"wɛl, jɛs," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ i fɔt wɪð ðə sɔɹd."

"Well, yes," Gawyn said. "But he fought with the sword."

ən ə wʊmən kʊdn juz ə sɔɹd? ðə saɪz ə ðə pɝsən jə sɔ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ə wʊmən."

And a woman couldn't use a sword? The size of the person you saw indicated a woman."

meɪbi, bʌt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən? laɪt, ɛɡwin, ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn mi-sænə, ðən ʃiɾ əv juz ðə paʊɝ tə bɝn mi tə dʌst!"

Maybe, but one of the Forsaken? Light, Egwene, if it had been Me-saana, then she'd have used the Power to burn me to dust!"

ənʌðɝ ɹizən," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ðæt jə ʃəd nɑɾ əv dɪsoʊbeɪd mi. pɝhæps jəɹ ɹaɪt - pɝhæps ðɪs wɑz wʌn ə mɛsænəz mɪnjənz. eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛn əɹ ɡɹeɪ mæn. ɪf ðət wɝ ðə keɪs, aɪɾ əv əm kæptɪv ən bi eɪbəl tə lɝn əbaʊt mɛsænəz plɑts. ən ɡɔɪn, wʌɾ ɪf jə hæd faʊn mɛsænə? wʌt kəd juv dʌn?"

Another reason," Egwene said, "that you should not have disobeyed me. Perhaps you're right - perhaps this was one of Mesaana's minions. A Darkfriend or Gray Man. If that were the case, I'd have them captive and be able to learn about Mesaana's plots. And Gawyn, what if you had found Mesaana? What could you have done?"

hi lʊk daʊn ət ðə flɔɹ.

He looked down at the floor.

"aɪ toʊl jə ðəɾ aɪ hæd teɪkən pɹikɔʃənz," ʃi kəntɪnjud. 'æn stɪl jə dɪsoʊbeɪd! ən naʊ, kəz ʌv wʌt juv dʌn, ðə mɝɾɝɝ noʊz ðəɾ aɪ wɑz æntɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ hɝ. ʃɪl bi mɔɹ kɛɹfəl nɛks taɪm. haʊ mɛni laɪvz dʒju θɪŋk jə dʒʌs kɑst ʌs?"

"I told you that I had taken precautions," she continued. 'And still you disobeyed! And now, because of what you've done, the murderer knows that I was anticipating her. She'll be more careful next time. How many lives do you think you just cost us?"

ɡɔɪn kɛpt ɪz hænz ɪn ɪz læp, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd ðə fɪsts ðət ðeɪ hæd fɔɹmd. hi ʃʊɾə fɛlt əʃeɪmd, bʌɾ ɔl i kəd fil wɑz æŋɡɝ. ə ɹeɪdʒ i kʊdn ɪkspleɪn - fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ət hɪmsɛlf, bʌt moʊsli əɾ ɛɡwin fəɹ tɝnɪŋ ən ɑnəs mɪsteɪk ɪndə ə pɝsənəl əfɹʌnt.

Gawyn kept his hands in his lap, trying to hide the fists that they had formed. He should have felt ashamed, but all he could feel was anger. A rage he couldn't explain - frustration at himself, but mostly at Egwene for turning an honest mistake into a personal affront.

"ɪt simz tə mi," hi sɛd, "ðæt jə doʊnt wɑn ə wɔɹɾɝ əɾ ɔl. kəz əl tɛl ju, ɛɡwin, ɪf jə kæn stæn biɪŋ lʊkt æftɝ, ðən noʊ mæn wɪl du."

"It seems to me," he said, "that you don't want a Warder at all. Because I'll tell you, Egwene, if you can't stand being looked after, then no man will do."

"pɝhæps jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt," ʃi sɛd kɝtli. hɝ skɝts ɹʌsəld əz ʃi pʊld oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl, wɛn aʊɾ ən ðən pʊld ɪt kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ. nɑt kwaɪɾ ə slæm.

"Perhaps you are right," she said curtly. Her skirts rustled as she pulled open the door to the hall, went out and then pulled it closed behind her. Not quite a slam.

ɡɔɪn stʊɾ ʌp ən wɑntəd tə kɪk ðə dɔɹ. laɪt, wʌɾ ə mɛs ðɪs hæd bɪkʌm!

Gawyn stood up and wanted to kick the door. Light, what a mess this had become!

hi kəd hɪɹ ɛɡwin θɹu ðə dɔɹ, sɛndɪŋ ðə ɡɔkɝz bæk tə ðɛɹ bɛdz, ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd tə bi ɛkstʃɹə vɪdʒələn tənaɪt. ðət wɑz laɪkli fəɹ ʃoʊ. ʃi nu ðət ði əsæsən wʊdn tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn soʊ sun.

He could hear Egwene through the door, sending the gawkers back to their beds, ordering the Tower Guard to be extra vigilant tonight. That was likely for show. She knew that the assassin wouldn't try again so soon.

ɡɔɪn slɪpt aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum ən lɛft. ʃi noʊɾəd ɪz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ tə hɪm, ɪnstɛd tɝnɪŋ tə spik sɔfli wɪð sɪlviænə. ðə ɹɛd hæɾ ə ɡlɛɹ fəɹ ɡɔɪn ðət wʊɾə meɪɾ ə boʊldɝ wɪns.

Gawyn slipped out of the room and left. She noted his departure, but said nothing to him, instead turning to speak softly with Silviana. The Red had a glare for Gawyn that would have made a boulder wince.

ɡɔɪn pæst sɛvɹəl ɡɑɹdz u - fəɹ ðɛɹ pɑɹts - simd ɹɪspɛkfəl ʌv ɡɔɪn. əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ nu, hid fɔɪld ən ətɛmpt ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪnz laɪf. ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd tə ðɛɹ sælɹz. tʃʌbn stʊd nɪɹbaɪ, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə naɪf ðət hæd nɪɹli teɪkən ɡɔɪn ɪn ðə tʃɛst.

Gawyn passed several guards who - for their parts - seemed respectful of Gawyn. As far as they knew, he'd foiled an attempt on the Amyrlin's life. Gawyn nodded to their salures. Chubain stood nearby, inspecting the knife that had nearly taken Gawyn in the chest.

tʃʌbn hɛld ʌp ðə naɪf tə hɪm. "hæv jə ɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs?"

Chubain held up the knife to him. "Have you ever seen anything like this?"

ɡɔɪn tʊk ðə nɛɹoʊ, slik naɪf. ɪt wɑz bæləns fəɹ θɹoʊɪŋ, wɪð ə faɪn stil bleɪd ðət lʊk sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ən ɪlɔŋɡeɪɾəd kændəlz fleɪm. sɛɾ ɪndə ðə sɛntɝ wɝ θɹi bɪts ə blʌd- kʌlɝd ɹɑk, "wʌt kaɪndə stoʊn ɪz ðæt?" ɡɔɪn æskt, hoʊldɪŋ ðə naɪf ʌp tə ðə laɪt.

Gawyn took the narrow, sleek knife. It was balanced for throwing, with a fine steel blade that looked something like an elongated candle's flame. Set into the center were three bits of blood- colored rock, "What kind of stone is that?" Gawyn asked, holding the knife up to the light.

"aɪv nɛvɝ sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ."

"I've never seen it before."

ɡɔɪn tɝn ðə naɪf oʊvɝ ə fju taɪmz. ðəɹ wɝn ɛni ɪnskɹɪpʃənz əɹ kɑɹvɪŋz. "ðɪs keɪm wɪðɪn hæf ə bɹɛθ ə kleɪmɪŋ maɪ laɪf."

Gawyn turned the knife over a few times. There weren't any inscriptions or carvings. "This came within half a breath of claiming my life."

"ju kən teɪk ɪt, ɪf jə wɪʃ," tʃʌbn sɛd. "meɪbi jə kən æsk bɹaɪnz mɛn ɪf ðeɪv ɛvɝ sin wʌn laɪk ɪt. wɪv ə sɛkənd wʌn wi faʊn daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ."

"You can take it, if you wish," Chubain said. "Maybe you can ask Bryne's men if they've ever seen one like it. We have a second one we found down the hallway."

"ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɪntɛndəd fəɹ maɪ hɑɹt," ɡɔɪn sɛd, tʌkɪŋ ðə naɪf ɪndə hɪz bɛlt. "θæŋk ju. aɪ hæv ə ɡɪft fəɹ jə ɪn ɹɪtɝn."

"It was also intended for my heart," Gawyn said, tucking the knife into his belt. "Thank you. I have a gift for you in return."

tʃʌbn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Chubain raised an eyebrow.

"juv bɪn kəmpleɪnɪŋ ə ðə mɛn jə lɔst," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wɛl, aɪv ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz aɪ kən ɹɛkəmɛn stʃɹɔŋli."

"You've been complaining of the men you lost," Gawyn said. "Well, I've a group of soldiers I can recommend strongly."

"fɹʌm bɹaɪnz ɑɹmi?" tʃʌbn æskt, lɪps daʊntɝnd. laɪk mɛni ʌv ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd, hi stɪl ɹəɡɑɹɾəd bɹaɪnz ɑɹmi əz ə ɹaɪvəl fɔɹs.

"From Bryne's army?" Chubain asked, lips downturned. Like many of the Tower Guard, he still regarded Bryne's army as a rival force.

"noʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "mɛn lɔɪəl tə ðə taʊɝ. səm ə ðoʊz u tʃɹeɪn tə bi wɔɹɾɝz ən u fɔt wɪð mi ɑn ɪleɪɾəz saɪd. ðəɹ filɪŋ dɪspleɪs naʊ, ən ðeɪ wəd ɹæðɝ bi soʊlʒɝz ðən wɔɹɾɝz. aɪɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪɾ ɪf jud ɡɪv əm ə hoʊm. ðəɹ sɑləd mɛn ən ɛksələnt wɔɹiɝz."

"No," Gawyn said. "Men loyal to the Tower. Some of those who trained to be Warders and who fought with me on Elaida's side. They're feeling displaced now, and they would rather be soldiers than Warders. I'd appreciate it if you'd give them a home. They're solid men and excellent warriors."

tʃʌbn nɑɾəd. "sɛn əm tə mi."

Chubain nodded. "Send them to me."

"ðeɪl kʌm tə jə təmɑɹoʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ oʊnli æsk wʌn θɪŋ. tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə bɹeɪk ðə ɡɹup əpɑɹt. ðeɪv bɪn θɹu mʌtʃ təɡɛðɝ. ðɛɹ bɑnd ɡɪvz əm stʃɹɛŋkθ."

"They'll come to you tomorrow," Gawyn said. "I only ask one thing. Try not to break the group apart. They've been through much together. Their bond gives them strength."

"ʃʊdn bi dɪfəkəlt," tʃʌbn sɛd. "ðə tɛnθ taʊɝ kʌmpəni wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd nɪɹli tə ə mæn baɪ ðoʊz fleɪmɪŋ sintʃæn. əl sɛt səm vɛɾɝən ɔfəsɝz oʊvɝ jəɹ lædz ən fɔɹm ðə nu kʌmpəni aʊɾ ə ðɛm."

"Shouldn't be difficult," Chubain said. "The Tenth Tower Company was destroyed nearly to a man by those flaming Seanchan. I'll set some veteran officers over your lads and form the new company out of them."

"θæŋk ju," ɡɔɪn sɛd. hi nɑɾəd təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwinz kɔɹɾɝz. "wɑtʃ oʊvɝ əɹ fəɹ mi, tʃʌbn. aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz dɪtɝmən tə si hɝsɛlf dɛd."

"Thank you," Gawyn said. He nodded toward Egwene's quarters. "Watch over her for me, Chubain. I think she's determined to see herself dead."

"ɪɾ ɪz ɛvɝ maɪ duɾi tə dɪfɛn ən əphoʊl ði æmɪɝlɪn. bʌt wɛɹ wɪl jə bi?"

"It is ever my duty to defend and uphold the Amyrlin. But where will you be?"

"ʃi meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ðət ʃi wɑns noʊ wɔɹɾɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd, hɪz maɪn dʒɹɪftɪŋ bæk tə ðə θɪŋz bɹaɪn hæd sɛd tə hɪm ɝliɝ. wʌɾ i wɑnt, əsaɪd fɹəm ɛɡwin? pɝhæps ɪt wɑz taɪm tə faɪn aʊt.

"She made it clear that she wants no Warder," Gawyn said, his mind drifting back to the things Bryne had said to him earlier. What did he want, aside from Egwene? Perhaps it was time to find out.

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪts pæs taɪm aɪ wɛn tə vɪzət maɪ sɪstɝ."

"I think it's past time I went to visit my sister."

tʃʌbn nɑɾəd, ən ɡɔɪn tʊk ɪz liv. hi vɪzəɾəd ðə bæɹəks ən ɡæðɝɾ ɪz pəzɛʃənz  - lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə tʃeɪnʒ ə kloʊðɪŋ ən ə wɪntɝ kloʊk - ðən meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə steɪbəlz ən sæɾəld tʃælənʒ.

Chubain nodded, and Gawyn took his leave. He visited the barracks and gathered his possessions  - little more than a change of clothing and a winter cloak - then made his way to the stables and saddled Challenge.

ðən i lɛd ðə hɔɹs tə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. ɛɡwin meɪnteɪn ə sɪstɝ ɑn duɾi ðəɹ əɾ ɔl taɪmz. tənaɪts ɛɛs sədaɪ - ə pətit, dʒɹaʊzi-aɪd ɡɹin neɪm naɪmɹi - dɪdn kwɛstʃən hɪm. ʃi meɪɾ ɪm ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ə hɪlsaɪɾ əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝz tʃɹævəl fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn.

Then he led the horse to the Traveling ground. Egwene maintained a sister on duty there at all times. Tonight's Aes Sedai - a petite, drowsy-eyed Green named Nimri - didn't question him. She made him a gateway to a hillside about an hour's travel from Caemlyn.

ən soʊ hi lɛf tɑɹ vəlɑn - ən ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ - bɪhaɪnd.

And so he left Tar Valon - and Egwene al'Vere - behind.

wʌɾ ɪz ðæt?" læn dɪmændəd.

What is that?" Lan demanded.

ði eɪdʒɪd nɑzɑɹ lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, lɛðɝ hædɔɹi hoʊldɪŋ daʊn ɪz paʊɾɝi waɪt hɛɹ. ə smɔl stʃɹim ɡɝɡəl nɪɹ ðɛɹ kæmp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə fɔɹəst ə haɪlən paɪnz. ðoʊz paɪnz ʃʊdn əv bɔɹn hæf soʊ mɛni bɹaʊn niɾəlz.

The aged Nazar looked up from his saddlebags, leather hadori holding down his powdery white hair. A small stream gurgled near their camp in the middle of a forest of highland pines. Those pines shouldn't have borne half so many brown needles.

nɑzɑɹ hæd bɪn tʌkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, ən læn hæd hæpən tə spɑɾ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɡoʊl pikɪŋ aʊt. "ðɪs?" nɑzɑɹ æskt. hi pʊl ðə klɔθ aʊt: ə bɹɪljənt waɪt flæɡ wɪð ə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ðə sɛntɝ. ɪt wɑz ə faɪn wɝk, wɪð bjuɾəfəl stɪtʃɪŋ. læn nɪɹli ɡɹæbd ɪɾ aʊɾ ə nɑzɑɹz fɪŋɡɝz ən ɹɪpt ɪɾ ɪn hæf.

Nazar had been tucking something into his saddlebags, and Lan had happened to spot a bit of gold peeking out. "This?" Nazar asked. He pulled the cloth out: a brilliant white flag with a golden crane embroidered in the center. It was a fine work, with beautiful stitching. Lan nearly grabbed it out of Nazar's fingers and ripped it in half.

"naʊ, aɪ si ðəɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn jəɹ feɪs, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən," nɑzɑɹ sɛd. "waɪl, doʊn jə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɔl sɛlf-sɛntɝɾ əbaʊt ðɪs. ə mæn əz ə ɹaɪt tə kæɹi hɪz kɪŋdəmz flæɡ wɪð hɪm."

"Now, I see that expression on your face, Lan Mandragoran," Nazar said. "Weil, don't you be getting all self-centered about this. A man has a right to carry his kingdom's flag with him."

"jɔɹ ə beɪkɝ, nɑzɑɹ."

"You're a baker, Nazar."

"ɪm ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ fɝst, sʌn," ðə mæn sɛd, tʌkɪŋ ðə bænɝ əweɪ "ðɪs ɪz maɪ hɛɹəɾədʒ."

"I'm a Borderlander first, son," the man said, tucking the banner away "This is my heritage."

"bɑ!" læn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. ði ʌðɝz wɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌp kæmp. hid ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli əlaʊd ðə θɹi nukʌmɝz tə dʒɔɪn ɪm - ðeɪ wɝ stʌbɝn əz bɔɹz, ən ɪn ði ɛnd, hi hæd hæd tə səkʌm tə hɪz oʊθ. hid pɹɑməs ðət hiɾ æksɛp fɑloʊɝz. ðiz mɛn, tɛknɪkəli, hædn æsk tə ɹaɪd wɪð ɪm - ðeɪd sɪmpli stɑɹɾəd duɪŋ ɪt. ðət wɑz ɪnʌf. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə tʃɹævəl ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən, ðən ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl sɛns ɪn meɪkɪŋ tu kæmps.

"Bah!" Lan said, turning away. The others were breaking up camp. He'd grudgingly allowed the three newcomers to join him - they were stubborn as boars, and in the end, he had had to succumb to his oath. He'd promised that he'd accept followers. These men, technically, hadn't asked to ride with him - they'd simply started doing it. That was enough. Besides, if they were going to travel in the same direction, then there was little sense in making two camps.

læn kəntɪnjud tə waɪp ɪz feɪs dʒɹaɪ fɹəm ðə mɔɹnɪŋz wɑʃɪŋ. bʌlən wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ bɹɛd ɹɛɾi fəɹ bɹɛkfəst. ðɪs ɡɹoʊv ə paɪnz wɑz ɪn istɝn kændɝ; ðeɪ wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊz tə ðə bɔɹɾɝ ɪndə ɝæfəl. pɝhæps i kəd -  hi fɹoʊz. ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl nu tɛns ɪn ðɛɹ kæmp. ə ɡɹup ʌv eɪt mɛn wɝ tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ændɪɹ. θɹi ʌv əm lʊk plʌmp ɝaʊn ðə weɪst - nɑt wɔɹiɝz, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ðɛɹ sɑf kloʊðɪŋ, ðoʊ ðeɪ dɪɾ əpɪɹ tə bi mɔlkɪɹi. ði ʌðɝ faɪv wɝ ɔl ʃaɪnɝənz, tɑpnɑts ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz, lɛðɝ bɹeɪsɝz ɑn ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, ən hɔɹsboʊz stɔɹɾ ɪn keɪsəz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks bɪsaɪd lɔŋ, tu-hændəd sɔɹdz.

Lan continued to wipe his face dry from the morning's washing. Bulen was getting bread ready for breakfast. This grove of pines was in eastern Kandor; they were getting close to the border into Arafel. Perhaps he could -  He froze. There were several new tents in their camp. A group of eight men were chatting with Andere. Three of them looked plump around the waist - not warriors, judging by their soft clothing, though they did appear to be Malkieri. The other five were all Shienarans, topknots on their heads, leather bracers on their arms, and horsebows stored in cases on their backs beside long, two-handed swords.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" læn dɪmændəd.

"What is this?" Lan demanded.

"wlɪn, mænəɡæn ən ɡɔɹnɛlɪn," ændɪɹ sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ðə mɔlkɪɹi. "ðiz ʌðɝz ɑɹ ki, dʒoʊoʊ, mɹɪkəl, iænɝ, kun - "

"Weilin, Managan and Gorenellin," Andere said, gesturing to the Malkieri. "These others are Qi, Joao, Merekel, Ianor, Kuehn - "

"aɪ dɪdn æsk hu," læn sɛd, vɔɪs koʊld. "aɪ æskt wʌt. wʌɾ əv jə dʌn?"

"I didn't ask who," Lan said, voice cold. "I asked what. What have you done?"

ændɪɹ ʃɹʌɡd. "wi mɛɾ əm bɪfɔɹ ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə ju. wi toʊld əm tə weɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə sʌðɝn ɹoʊdweɪ fəɹ ʌs. ɹɑkim fɛtʃt əm læs naɪt, waɪl jə wɝ slipɪŋ."

Andere shrugged. "We met them before running into you. We told them to wait along the southern roadway for us. Rakim fetched them last night, while you were sleeping."

"ɹɑkim wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɑn wɑtʃ!" læn sɛd.

"Rakim was supposed to be on watch!" Lan said.

"aɪ wɑtʃt ɪn ɪz stɛd," ændɪɹ sɛd. "aɪ fɪɡjɝd wid wɑn ðiz fɛl-loʊz."

"I watched in his stead," Andere said. "I figured we'd want these fel-lows."

ɔl θɹi ʌv ðə plʌmp mɝtʃəns lʊk tə læn, ðən wɛn daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ niz. wʌn wɑz wipɪŋ oʊpənli. "teɪʃɝ mɔlkiɝ." ðə faɪv ʃaɪnɝənz səluɾəd læn. "daɪ ʃæn," wʌn sɛd. "wi hæv bɹɔt wʌt wi kəd tə ðə kɑz ə ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn," ənʌðɝ ə ðə mɝtʃəns æɾəd. "ɔl ðət wi kəd ɡæðɝ ɪn ə lɪɾəl taɪm." "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt mʌtʃ," sɛd ðə θɝd. "bʌt wi lɛn jə əɹ sɔɹdz əz wɛl. wi meɪ lʊk tə hæv ɡɹoʊn sɑft, bʌt wi kən faɪt. wɪl faɪt." "aɪ doʊnt nid wʌt jə bɹɔt," læn sɛd, ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd. "aɪ - " "bɪfɔɹ jə seɪ tu mʌtʃ mɔɹ, oʊl fɹɛnd," ændɪɹ sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn lænz ʃoʊldɝ, "pɝhæps jə ʃəɾ əv ə lʊk ət ðæt." hi nɑɾəd tə ðə saɪd.

All three of the plump merchants looked to Lan, then went down on their knees. One was weeping openly. "Tai'shar Malkier." The five Shienarans saluted Lan. "Dai Shan," one said. "We have brought what we could to the cause of the Golden Crane," another of the merchants added. "All that we could gather in a little time." "It is not much," said the third. "But we lend you our swords as well. We may look to have grown soft, but we can fight. We will fight." "I don't need what you brought," Lan said, exasperated. "I - " "Before you say too much more, old friend," Andere said, laying a hand on Lan's shoulder, "perhaps you should have a look at that." He nodded to the side.

læn fɹaʊnd, hɪɹɪŋ ə ɹætlɪŋ saʊnd. hi stɛpt pæst ə pætʃ ə tʃɹiz tə lʊk əpɑn ðə pæθ tə ðə kæmp. tu dʌzən wæɡənz wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, itʃ paɪl haɪ wɪð səplaɪz - wɛpənz, sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn, tɛns. læn oʊpən ɪz aɪz waɪd. ə ɡʊd dʌzən wɔɹhɔɹsɪz wɝ hɪtʃt ɪn ə laɪn, ən stʃɹɔŋ ɑksən pʊl ðə wæɡənz. timstɝz ən sɝvəns wɔkt əlɔŋsaɪd ðɛm.

Lan frowned, hearing a rattling sound. He stepped past a patch of trees to look upon the path to the camp. Two dozen wagons were approaching, each piled high with supplies - weapons, sacks of grain, tents. Lan opened his eyes wide. A good dozen warhorses were hitched in a line, and strong oxen pulled the wagons. Teamsters and servants walked alongside them.

"wɛn ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪ soʊld wʌt ðeɪ kəɾ ən bɹɔt səplaɪz," ændɪɹ sɛd, "ðeɪ mɛn ɪt."

"When they said they sold what they could and brought supplies," Andere said, "they meant it."

"wi wɪl nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə muv kwaɪətli wɪð ɔl ə ðɪs!" læn sɛd.

"We will never be able to move quietly with all of this!" Lan said.

ændɪɹ ʃɹʌɡd.

Andere shrugged.

læn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. vɛɹi wɛl. hi wəd wɝk wɪð ɪt. "muvɪŋ kwaɪətli əpɪɹz tə bi feɪlɪŋ ɛniweɪ. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, wɪl poʊz əz ə kæɹəvæn dɪlɪvɝɪŋ səplaɪz tə ʃaɪnɝ."

Lan took a deep breath. Very well. He would work with it. "Moving quietly appears to be failing anyway. From now on, we will pose as a caravan delivering supplies to Shienar."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ju wɪl swɛɹ tə mi," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə mɛn. "itʃ ə jəl swɛɹ nɑt tə ɹɪvil u aɪm əɹ sɛnd wɝd tə ɛniwʌn ɛls u maɪt bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi. jəl swɛɹ ɪt"

"You will swear to me," he said, turning toward the men. "Each of you will swear not to reveal who I am or send word to anyone else who might be looking for me. You will swear it"

nɑzɑɹ lʊk laɪk i wəɾ əbdʒɛkt, bʌt læn saɪlənst ɪm wɪð ə stɝn lʊk. wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðeɪ swɔɹ.

Nazar looked like he would object, but Lan silenced him with a stern look. One by one, they swore.

ðə faɪv hæd bɪkʌm dʌzənz, bʌɾ ɪt wəd stɑp ðɛɹ.

The five had become dozens, but it would stop there.

tə meɪk ə stænd


To Make a Stand

bɛd ɹɛst," mɛlfən ənaʊnst, teɪkɪŋ əɹ ɪɹ fɹəm ðə wʊɾən tub ʃid pleɪst əɡɛnst ɪleɪnz tʃɛst. ðə mɪdwaɪf wɑz ə ʃɔɹt, æmpəl-tʃikt wʊmən u tədeɪ wɔɹ əɹ hɛɹ taɪd bæk baɪ ə tʃɹænslusən blu skɑɹf. hɝ nit dʒɹɛs wɑz ʌv waɪɾ ən mætʃɪŋ skaɪ-blu, əz ɪf wɔɹn ɪn dɪfaɪəns ə ðə pɝpɛtʃuəli oʊvɝkæst skaɪ.

Bed rest," Melfane announced, taking her ear from the wooden tube she'd placed against Elayne's chest. The midwife was a short, ample-cheeked woman who today wore her hair tied back by a translucent blue scarf. Her neat dress was of white and matching sky-blue, as if worn in defiance of the perpetually overcast sky.

"wʌt?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"What?" Elayne asked.

"wʌn wik," mɛlfən sɛd, wæɡɪŋ ə θɪk fɪŋɡɝ əɾ ɪleɪn. "ju ɑɹən tə bi ɑn jəɹ fit fəɹ wʌn wik."

"One week," Melfane said, wagging a thick finger at Elayne. "You aren't to be on your feet for one week."

ɪleɪn blɪŋkt, stʌnd, hɝ ɪɡzɔstʃən fliɪŋ fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. mɛlfən smaɪl tʃɪɹfəli əz ʃi kənsaɪn ɪleɪn tə ðɪs ɪmpɑsəbəl pʌnɪʃmənt. bɛd ɹɛst? fəɹ ə wik?

Elayne blinked, stunned, her exhaustion fleeing for the moment. Melfane smiled cheerfully as she consigned Elayne to this impossible punishment. Bed rest? For a week?

bɝdʒɪt stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, mæt ɪn ðə ɹum bɪɑnd. hid stɛpt aʊt fəɹ mɛlfənz ɪnspɛkʃən, bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz hid hʌvɝd nɪɹ əɹ ɔlmoʊst əz pɹoʊtɛktɪvli əz bɝdʒɪt. jud nɛvɝ noʊ ðeɪ kɛɹd fəɹ əɹ baɪ ðə weɪ ðeɪ spoʊk, haʊɛvɝ - ðə tu ʌv əm hæd bɪn ʃɛɹɪŋ kɝsɪz, itʃ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɑp ði ʌðɝ. ɪleɪn hæd lɝn ə fju nu wʌnz. hu nu ðət hʌnʒɹəd-lɛɡz dɪd ðoʊz θɪŋz?

Birgitte stood in the doorway, Mat in the room beyond. He'd stepped out for Melfane's inspection, but otherwise he'd hovered near her almost as protectively as Birgitte. You'd never know they cared for her by the way they spoke, however - the two of them had been sharing curses, each trying to top the other. Elayne had learned a few new ones. Who knew that hundred-legs did those things?

hɝ beɪbz wɝ seɪf, soʊ fɑɹ əz mɛlfən kəd tɛl. ðət wɑz ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt pɑɹt. "bɛd ɹɛst ɪz, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪmpɑsəbəl," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæv fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ tə du."

Her babes were safe, so far as Melfane could tell. That was the important part. "Bed rest is, of course, impossible," Elayne said. "I have far too much to do."

"wɛl, ɪɾəl əv tə bi dʌn fɹəm bɛd," mɛlfən ɹɪplaɪd, hɝ vɔɪs plɛzən bʌt kəmplitli ənjildɪŋ. "jɔɹ bɑɾi ən jəɹ tʃaɪld əv ʌndɝɡɔn ə ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛs. ðeɪ nid taɪm tə ɹɪkʌvɝ. əl bi ətɛndɪŋ jə ən meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən jə meɪnteɪn ə stʃɹɪk daɪət."

"Well, it will have to be done from bed," Melfane replied, her voice pleasant but completely unyielding. "Your body and your child have undergone a great stress. They need time to recover. I will be attending you and making certain you maintain a strict diet."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"aɪ woʊn hɪɹ ɛni ɪkskjusɪz," mɛlfən ɪntɝʌptɪd.

"ɪm ðə kwinəl" ɪleɪn sɛd, ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd.

ʃi mɛɾ ɪleɪnz aɪz. "wʊd jə laɪk tə pʊt maɪ wɝdz tə ðə tɛst, jəɹ mædʒəsti?"

that nod seemed to say.

And would you keep me here forever?" Elayne asked. "Like Gelfina, from the stories, locked away for a thousand years in the forgotten tower?" Birgitte sighed. "No. But six months or so would help keep my anxiety levels down."

"wi doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ ðæt," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "wi doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ mʌtʃ, ðiz deɪz. ɹɪsks mʌs bi teɪkən."

"We don't have time for that," Elayne replied. "We don't have time for much, these days. Risks must be taken."

"ɹɪsks ɪnvɑlvɪŋ ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əloʊn tə feɪs ə mɑb ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ? jəɹ laɪk səm blʌd-bɛsɑɾɪd ɪɾiət ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild, tʃɑɹɡ-ɪŋ əhɛɾ ə hɪz kɑmɹædz, sikɪŋ dɛθ wɪθaʊɾ ə ʃild-meɪt tə ɡɑɹd jəɹ bæk!

"Risks involving the Queen of Andor going alone to face a mob of the Black Ajah? You're like some blood-besotted idiot on the battlefield, charg-ing ahead of his comrades, seeking death without a shield-mate to guard your back!

ɪleɪn blɪŋkt ət ði æŋɡɝ ɪn ðə wʊmən.

Elayne blinked at the anger in the woman.

"doʊn jə tʃɹʌs mi, ɪleɪn?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt. "wʊd jə bi ɹɪɾ ə mi, ɪf jə kʊd?"

"Don't you trust me, Elayne?" Birgitte asked. "Would you be rid of me, if you could?"

"wʌt? noʊ! ʌv kɔɹs aɪ tʃɹʌs ju."

"What? No! Of course I trust you."

"ðɛn waɪ woʊn jə lemi hɛlp ju? aɪm nɑt səpoʊz tə bi hɪɹ, naʊ. aɪ hæv noʊ pɝpəs ʌðɝ ðən wʌt sɝkəmstæns əz ɡɪvən mi. jə meɪd mi jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ, bʌt jə woʊn lemi pɹətɛk ju!

"Then why won't you let me help you? I'm not supposed to be here, now. I have no purpose other than what circumstance has given me. You made me your Warder, but you won't let me protect you!

haʊ kən aɪ bi jəɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd ɪf jə woʊn tɛl mi wən jəɹ pʊɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ?"

How can I be your bodyguard if you won't tell me when you're putting yourself in danger?"

ɪleɪn fɛlt laɪk pʊlɪŋ ðə kʌvɝz ʌp tə ʃil hɝsɛlf fɹəm ðoʊz aɪz. haʊ kəd bɝdʒɪt bi ðə wʌn u fɛl soʊ hɝt? ɪleɪn hæd bɪn ðə wʌn hud bɪn wundəd! "ɪf ɪt minz ɛniθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə də ðɪs əɡɛn."

Elayne felt like pulling the covers up to shield herself from those eyes. How could Birgitte be the one who felt so hurt? Elayne had been the one who'd been wounded! "If it means anything," she said, "I don't intend to do this again."

"noʊ. jəl də sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɹɛkləs."

"No. You'll do something else reckless."

"aɪ min, aɪ ɪntɛn tə bi mɔɹ kɛɹfəl. meɪbi jəɹ ɹaɪt, ən ðə vjuɪŋ ɪzən ə pɝfəkt ɡɛɹənti.

"I mean, I intend to be more careful. Maybe you're right, and the viewing isn't a perfect guarantee.

ɪt sɝɾənli dɪdn stɑp mi fɹəm pænɪkɪŋ wən aɪ fɛlt ə ɹil deɪnʒɝ."

It certainly didn't stop me from panicking when I felt a real danger."

"ju dɪdn fil ə ɹil deɪnʒɝ wən ðə blæk ədʒɑ lɑk jə ʌp ən tʃɹaɪd tə kɑɹt jə əweɪ?"

"You didn't feel a real danger when the Black Ajah locked you up and tried to cart you away?"

ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn fɹaɪɾənd ðət taɪm, bʌt ʃi hædn bɪn. nɑɾ oʊnli kəz ə mɪnz vjuɪŋ. ðə blæk ədʒɑ wəd nɛvɝ əv kɪl hɝ, nɑɾ ʌndɝ ðoʊz sɝkəmstænsəz. ʃi wɑz tu væljəbəl.

Elayne hesitated. She should have been frightened that time, but she hadn't been. Not only because of Min's viewing. The Black Ajah would never have killed her, not under those circumstances. She was too valuable.

filɪŋ ðət naɪf ɛntɝ əɹ saɪd, pɪɹs əɹ skɪn, dɪɡ təwɔɹɾ əɹ wum . . . ðət hæd bɪn dɪfɹənt.

Feeling that knife enter her side, pierce her skin, dig toward her womb . . . that had been different.

ðə tɛɹɝ. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə wɝl blækənɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ, hɝ hɑɹtbit θəɾɪŋ, ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ, laɪk ðə dʒɹʌmbits ət ði ɛn ʌv ə pɝfɔɹməns. ðə wʌnz ðət keɪm bɪfɔɹ ðə saɪləns.

The terror. She could remember the world blackening around her, her heartbeat thudding, growing louder, like the drumbeats at the end of a performance. The ones that came before the silence.

bɝdʒɪt ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪleɪn əpɹeɪzɪŋli. ʃi kəd fil ɪleɪnz ɪmoʊʃənz. ʃi wɑz kwin. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əvɔɪd ɹɪsks. bʌt. . . pɝhæps ʃi kəd ɹeɪn hɝsɛlf ɪn.

Birgitte regarded Elayne appraisingly. She could feel Elayne's emotions. She was Queen. She could not avoid risks. But. . . perhaps she could rein herself in.

"wɛl," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, "dɪd jə ət lis dɪskʌvɝ ɛniθɪŋ?"

"Well," Birgitte said, "did you at least discover anything?"

"aɪ dɪd," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ - "

"I did," Elayne said. "I - "

ət ðət moʊmənt, ə skɑɹf-ɹæp hɛɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. mæt hæɾ ɪz aɪz kloʊzd. "ju kʌvɝɾ ʌp?"

At that moment, a scarf-wrapped head appeared in the doorway. Mat had his eyes closed. "You covered up?"

"jɛs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "æn ɪn ə fɑɹ mɔɹ fæʃənəbəl weɪ ðən ju, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. ðət skɑɹf lʊks ɹɪdɪkjələs."

"Yes," Elayne said. "And in a far more fashionable way than you, Matrim Cauthon. That scarf looks ridiculous."

hi skaʊld, oʊpənɪŋ ɪz aɪz ən pʊlɪŋ ɔf ðə skɑɹf, ɹɪvilɪŋ ði æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs bɪniθ. "ju tʃɹaɪ muvɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ɹɛk-ɑɡnaɪzd," hi sɛd.

He scowled, opening his eyes and pulling off the scarf, revealing the angular face beneath. "You try moving through the city without being rec-ognized," he said.

"ɛvɹi bʊtʃɝ, ɪnkipɝ ən blʌɾi bækɹum slɪpfɪn-ɡɝ simz tə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ lʊk laɪk ðiz deɪz." "ðə blæk sɪstɝz wɝ plænɪŋ tə hæv jə əsæsəneɪɾəd," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"Every butcher, innkeeper and bloody backroom slipfin-ger seems to know what I look like these days." "The Black sisters were planning to have you assassinated," Elayne said.

"wʌt?" mæt æskt.

"What?" Mat asked.

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd. "wʌn mɛnʃən ju. ɪt saʊndəd laɪk dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd bɪn sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ jə fəɹ səm taɪm, wɪð ði ɪntɛn ə kɪlɪŋ ju."

Elayne nodded. "One mentioned you. It sounded like Darkfriends had been searching for you for some time, with the intent of killing you."

bɝdʒɪt ʃɹʌɡd. "ðeɪɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. noʊ daʊt ðeɪ wɑn əs ɔl dɛd."

Birgitte shrugged. "They're Darkfriends. No doubt they want us all dead."

"ðɪs wɑz dɪfɹənt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɪt simd mɔɹ . . . ɪntɛns. aɪ sədʒɛs kipɪŋ jəɹ wɪts əbaʊt jə ðə nɛkst waɪl."

"This was different," Elayne said. "It seemed more . . . intense. I suggest keeping your wits about you the next while."

"ðæɾəl bi ə tʃɹɪk," bɝdʒɪt noʊɾəd. "siɪŋ əz tə haʊ hi dʌzn əv ɛni wɪts ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs."

"That'll be a trick," Birgitte noted. "Seeing as to how he doesn't have any wits in the first place."

mæt ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz. "dɪɾ aɪ mɪs jə ɪkspleɪnɪŋ wʌt jə wɝ duɪŋ ɪn ðə fleɪmɪŋ dʌnʒənz, sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə pul ə jəɹ oʊn blʌd, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld laɪk jud sin ðə luzɪŋ ɛn ʌv ə bæɾəlfild skɝmɪʃ?"

Mat rolled his eyes. "Did I miss you explaining what you were doing in the flaming dungeons, sitting in a pool of your own blood, looking for all the world like you'd seen the losing end of a battlefield skirmish?"

"aɪ wɑz ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðə dɪteɪlz ɑɹ nʌn ə jəɹ kənsɝn. bɝdʒɪt, hæv jə ə ɹipɔɹt fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnz?"

"I was interrogating the Black Ajah," Elayne said. "The details are none of your concern. Birgitte, have you a report from the grounds?"

"noʊbɑdi sɔ mɛlɝ liv," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd. "ðoʊ wi faʊn ðə sɛkɹətɛɹiz bɑɾi ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ, stɪl wɔɹm. daɪd fɹəm ə naɪf tə ðə bæk."

"Nobody saw Mellar leave," the Warder said. "Though we found the secretary's body on the ground floor, still warm. Died from a knife to the back."

ɪleɪn saɪd. "ʃieɪn?"

Elayne sighed. "Shiaine?"

"ɡɔn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, "əlɔŋ wɪð mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn ən fæljən boʊɾə."

"Gone," Birgitte said, "along with Marillin Gemalphin and Falion Bhoda."

"ðə ʃædoʊ kʊdn liv əm ɪn əɹ pəzɛʃən," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪð ə saɪ. "ðeɪ noʊ tu mʌtʃ. ðeɪ hæd tə ɛn ʌp iðɝ ɹɛskjuɾ əɹ ɛksəkjuɾəd."

"The Shadow couldn't leave them in our possession," Elayne said with a sigh. "They know too much. They had to end up either rescued or executed."

'wɛl," mæt sɛd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ, "jɔɹ əlaɪv, ən θɹi ʌv əm ɑɹ dɛd. simz laɪk ə ɹizənəbli ɡʊɾ aʊtkʌm."

'Well," Mat said, shrugging, "you're alive, and three of them are dead. Seems like a reasonably good outcome."

bʌt ðə wʌnz u ɪskeɪpt əv ə kɑpi ʌv jəɹ mədæljən, ɪleɪn θɔt. ʃi dɪdn spik ɪt, haʊɛvɝ. ʃi ɔlsoʊ dɪdn mɛnʃən ði ɪnveɪʒən ðət tʃɛzməl hæd spoʊkən ʌv. ʃi wəd tɔk ʌv ɪt wɪð bɝdʒɪt sun, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt fɝst ʃi wɑntəd tə kənsɪɾɝ ɪt hɝsɛlf.

But the ones who escaped have a copy of your medallion, Elayne thought. She didn't speak it, however. She also didn't mention the invasion that Chesmal had spoken of. She would talk of it with Birgitte soon, of course, but first she wanted to consider it herself.

mæt hæd sɛd ðə naɪts ɪvɛns hæɾ ə "ɹizənəbli ɡʊɾ aʊtkʌm." bʌt ðə mɔɹ ɪleɪn θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðə mɔɹ dɪsæɾəsfaɪd ʃi wɑz. ən ɪnvə- sən ʌv ændɝ wɑz kʌmɪŋ, bʌt ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wɛn. ðə ʃædoʊ wɑntəd mæt dɛd, bʌɾ əz bɝdʒɪt hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt, ðət wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz. ɪn fækt, ði oʊnli sɝɾən ɹɪzʌlt ə ði ivnɪŋz ædvɛntʃɝz wɑz ðə sɛns ə fətiɡ ɪleɪn fɛlt. ðəɾ ən ə wik kənfaɪn tə hɝ ɹumz.

Mat had said the night's events had a "reasonably good outcome." But the more Elayne thought about it, the more dissatisfied she was. An inva- sion of Andor was coming, but she didn't know when. The Shadow wanted Mat dead, but as Birgitte had pointed out, that was no surprise. In fact, the only certain result of the evening's adventures was the sense of fatigue Elayne felt. That and a week confined to her rooms.

"mæt," ʃi sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz mədæljən. "hɪɹ, ɪts taɪm aɪ ɡeɪv ðɪs bæk. jə ʃəd noʊ ðəɾ ɪt pɹɑbli seɪv maɪ laɪf tənaɪt."

"Mat," she said, taking off his medallion. "Here, it's time I gave this back. You should know that it probably saved my life tonight."

hi wɔkt oʊvɝ ən tʊk ɪt bæk iɡɝli, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "wɝ jə eɪbəl tə . . ."

He walked over and took it back eagerly, then hesitated. "Were you able to . . ."

"kɑpi ɪt? nɑt pɝfəkli. bʌt tə ən ɪkstɛnt."

"Copy it? Not perfectly. But to an extent."

hi pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɑn, lʊkɪŋ kənsɝnd. "wɛl, ðət filz ɡʊd tə hæv bæk. aɪv bɪn wɑntɪŋ tə æsk jə sʌmθɪŋ. naʊ maɪt nɑt bi ðə taɪm"

He put it back on, looking concerned. "Well, that feels good to have back. I've been wanting to ask you something. Now might not be the time"

"spik ʌv ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd, taɪɝd. "maɪɾ əz wɛl."

"Speak of it," Elayne said, tired. "Might as well."

"wɛl, ɪts əbaʊt ðə ɡoʊləm . . ."

"Well, it's about the gholam . . ."

"ðə sɪɾi hæz bɪn ɛmptiɾ ə moʊst səvɪljənz," joʊli sɛɾ əz i ən ɪɾɝɑldi wɔk θɹu mɛɹədɑnz ɡeɪt. "wɝ kloʊs tə ðə blaɪt; ðɪs ɪz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm wiv ɪvækjəweɪɾɪd. maɪ oʊn sɪstɝ, sɪɡɹɪl, lidz ðə læstʃɹaɪɾɝz, hu wɪl wɑtʃ fɹəm ðə ɹɪdʒ tə ðə saʊθist ən sɛnd wɝɾ ɪf wi ʃəd wi fɔl. ʃɪl əv sɛnt wɝd tə əɹ wɑtʃpoʊsts ɝaʊn sɑldɑiə, ɹɪkwɛstɪŋ eɪd. ʃɪl laɪɾ ə wɑtʃfaɪɝ tə əlɝɾ əs ɪf ðeɪ kʌm."

"The city has been emptied of most civilians," Yoeli said as he and Ituralde walked through Maradon's gate. "We're close to the Blight; this is not the first time we've evacuated. My own sister, Sigril, leads the Lastriders, who will watch from the ridge to the southeast and send word if we should we fall. She will have sent word to our watchposts around Saldaea, requesting aid. She will light a watchfire to alert us if they come."

ðə lin-feɪs mæn lʊkt əɾ ɪɾɝɑldi, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹɪm. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi fju tʃɹups u kəd kʌm tə əɹ eɪd. kwin tɛnoʊbiə tʊk mɛni wɪð əɹ wən ʃi ɹoʊd tə faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

The lean-faced man looked at Ituralde, his expression grim. "There will be few troops who could come to our aid. Queen Tenobia took many with her when she rode to find the Dragon Reborn."

ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd. hi wɔkt wɪθaʊɾ ə lɪmp - ænteɪl, wʌn ə ði æʃəmən, wɑz kwaɪt skɪld wɪð hilɪŋ. hɪz mɛn meɪɾ ə heɪsti kæmp ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd teɪkən ðə tɛns ðeɪd lɛf bɪhaɪnd, ðən lɪɾ əm ɑn faɪɝ ət naɪt tə ɪlumɪnɪɾ əm fistɪŋ ɑn ðə wundəd.

Ituralde nodded. He walked without a limp - Antail, one of the Ashaman, was quite skilled with Healing. His men made a hasty camp in the courtyard just inside the city gates. The Trollocs had taken the tents they'd left behind, then lit them on fire at night to illuminate them feasting on the wounded.

ɪɾɝɑldi hæd muv səm ə hɪz tʃɹups ɪndə ði ɛmpti bɪldɪŋz, bʌɾ i wɑntəɾ ʌðɝz kloʊs tə ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪn keɪs ʌv ən əsɔlt.

Ituralde had moved some of his troops into the empty buildings, but he wanted others close to the gate in case of an assault.

ði æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd wɝk tə hil ɪɾɝɑldiz mɛn, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə wɝs keɪsəz kəd ɡɛɾ ətɛnʃən. ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd tə ænteɪl, hu wɑz wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə wundəɾ ɪn ə ɹoʊpt-ɔf sɛkʃən ə ðə skwɛɹ. ænteɪl dɪdn si ðə nɑd. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd, swɛɾɪŋ, wɝkɪŋ wɪð ə paʊɝ ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdnt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt.

The Ashaman and Aes Sedai had worked to Heal Ituralde's men, but only the worst cases could get attention. Ituralde nodded to Antail, who was working with the wounded in a roped-off section of the square. Antail didn't see the nod. He concentrated, sweating, working with a Power Ituralde didn't want to think about.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jə wɑnə si ðɛm?" joʊli æskt. hi hɛld ə hɔɹsmənz lɔŋ spɪɹ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ðə tɪp taɪd wɪð ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ blæk ən jɛloʊ pɛndənt. ɪt wɑz kɔl ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝz bænɝ baɪ ðə sɑldəiənz hɪɹ.

"Are you certain you want to see them?" Yoeli asked. He held a horsemans long spear on his shoulder, the tip tied with a triangular black and yellow pendant. It was called the Traitor's Banner by the Saldaeans here.

ðə sɪɾi bɹɪsəld wɪð hɑstɪləɾi, dɪfɹənt ɡɹups ə sɑldəiənz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð ɡɹɪm ɪkspɹɛʃənz. mɛni wɔɹ stʃɹɪps ə blæk klɔθ ən jɛloʊ klɔθ twɪstəɾ əbaʊt wʌn ənʌðɝ ən taɪd tə ðɛɹ sɔɹd ʃiθs. ðeɪ nɑɾəd tə joʊli.

The city bristled with hostility, different groups of Saldaeans regarding one another with grim expressions. Many wore strips of black cloth and yellow cloth twisted about one another and tied to their sword sheaths. They nodded to Yoeli.

deɪsjə ɡeɪveɪn siɹɾoʊ kwɛnʒɹ ɪeɪn kɛɹɛntɪn, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt. ə fɹeɪz ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ. ɪt mɛnt "ə ɹɛzəlut hɑɹɾ ɪz wɝθ tɛn ɑɹɡjəməns." hi kəd ɡɛs wʌt ðət bænɝ mɛnt. səmtaɪmz ə mæn nu wʌɾ i mʌs du, ðoʊ ɪt saʊndəd ɹɔŋ. ðə tu ʌv əm wɔk fəɹ ə taɪm θɹu ðə stʃɹits. mɛɹədɑn wɑz laɪk moʊs bɔɹɾɝlənd sɪɾiz: stʃɹeɪt wɔlz, skwɛɹ bɪldɪŋz, nɛɹoʊ stʃɹits.

Desya gavane cierto cuendar isain carentin, Ituralde thought. A phrase in the Old Tongue. It meant "A resolute heart is worth ten arguments." He could guess what that banner meant. Sometimes a man knew what he must do, though it sounded wrong. The two of them walked for a time through the streets. Maradon was like most Borderland cities: straight walls, square buildings, narrow streets.

ðə haʊsəz lʊk laɪk fɔɹtʃɹəs kips, wɪð smɔl wɪndoʊz ən stɝɾi dɔɹz ðə stʃɹits waʊn ɪn ɑd weɪz, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ θætʃt ɹufs - oʊnli sleɪt ʃɪŋɡəlz, faɪɝpɹuf. ðə dʒɹaɪd blʌɾ ət sɛvɹəl ki ɪntɝsɛkʃənz wɑz dɪfəkəl tə meɪk aʊɾ əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk stoʊn, bʌɾ ɪɾɝɑldi nu wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ. joʊliz ɹɛskju ʌv ɪz tʃɹups hæd kʌm æftɝ faɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə sɑldəiənz.

The houses looked like fortressed keeps, with small windows and sturdy doors The streets wound in odd ways, and there were no thatched roofs - only slate shingles, fireproof. The dried blood at several key intersections was difficult to make out against the dark stone, but Ituralde knew what to look for. Yoeli's rescue of his troops had come after fighting among the Saldaeans.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə nɑndɪskɹɪp bɪldɪŋ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ weɪ fəɹ ən aʊtsaɪɾɝ tə noʊ ðət ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ dwɛlɪŋ bɪlɔŋ tə vɹæm tɔɹku-mɛn, dɪstən kʌzən tə ðə kwin, əpɔɪntəd lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ɪn əɹ æbsəns. ðə soʊlʒɝz ət ðə dɔɹ wɔɹ jɛloʊ ən blæk. ðeɪ səluɾəd joʊli.

They reached a nondescript building. There would be no way for an outsider to know that this particular dwelling belonged to Vram Torku-men, distant cousin to the Queen, appointed lord of the city in her absence. The soldiers at the door wore yellow and black. They saluted Yoeli.

ɪnsaɪd, ɪɾɝɑldi ən joʊli ɛntɝɾ ə nɛɹoʊ stɛɹkeɪs ən klaɪm θɹi flaɪts ə stɛɹz. ðəɹ wɝ soʊlʒɝz ɪn nɪɹli ɛvɹi ɹum. ɑn ðə tɑp flɔɹ, fɔɹ mɛn wɛɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝz bænɝ ɡɑɹɾəd ə lɑɹdʒ, ɡoʊld-ɪnleɪd dɔɹ. ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz dɑɹk: nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊz, ə ɹʌɡ ʌv blæk, ɡɹin ən ɹɛd.

Inside, Ituralde and Yoeli entered a narrow staircase and climbed three flights of stairs. There were soldiers in nearly every room. On the top floor, four men wearing the Traitor's Banner guarded a large, gold-inlaid door. The hallway was dark: narrow windows, a rug of black, green and red.

"ɛniθɪŋ tə ɹipɔɹt, tɑɹən?" joʊli æskt.

"Anything to report, Tarran?" Yoeli asked.

"nɑɾ ə θɪŋ, sɝ," ðə mæn sɛd wɪð ə səlut. hi wɔɹ lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz ən hæd ðə baʊd lɛɡz ʌv ə mæn vɛɹi kʌmftəɹbəl ɪn ðə sæɾəl.

"Not a thing, sir," the man said with a salute. He wore long mustaches and had the bowed legs of a man very comfortable in the saddle.

joʊli nɑɾəd. "θæŋk ju, tɑɹən. fəɹ ɔl jə du."

Yoeli nodded. "Thank you, Tarran. For all you do."

"aɪ stænd wɪð ju, sɝ. ən wɪl ət ði ɛnd."

"I stand with you, sir. And will at the end."

"meɪ jə kip jəɹ aɪz nɔɹθwɝd, bʌt jəɹ hɑɹt saʊθwɝd, maɪ fɹɛnd," joʊli sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ ən pʊʃɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. ɪɾɝɑldi fɑloʊd.

"May you keep your eyes northward, but your heart southward, my friend," Yoeli said, taking a deep breath and pushing open the door. Ituralde followed.

ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum, ə sɑldəiən mæn ɪn ə ɹɪtʃ ɹɛd ɹoʊb sæt bɪsaɪɾ ə hɑɹθ, sɪpɪŋ ə kʌp ʌv waɪn. ə wʊmən ɪn ə faɪn dʒɹɛs dɪd niɾəlwɝk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ əkɹɔs fɹəm hɪm. niðɝ lʊkt ʌp.

Inside the room, a Saldaean man in a rich red robe sat beside a hearth, sipping a cup of wine. A woman in a fine dress did needlework in the chair across from him. Neither looked up.

"lɔɹd tɔɹkjəmɛn," joʊli sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi, liɾɝ ə ðə dəmɑni ɑɹmi."

"Lord Torkumen," Yoeli said. "This is Rodel Ituralde, leader of the Domani army."

ðə mæn ət ðə hɑɹθ saɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz kʌp ʌv waɪn. "ju də nɑt nɑk, jə də nɑt weɪt fəɹ mi tə ædʒɹɛs jə fɝst, jə kʌm dʊɹɪŋ ən aʊɝ wən əv spoʊkən ə maɪ nid fəɹ kwaɪət kɑntəmpleɪʃən."

The man at the hearth sighed over his cup of wine. "You do not knock, you do not wait for me to address you first, you come during an hour when have spoken of my need for quiet contemplation."

ɹɪli, vɹæm," ðə wʊmən sɛd, "ju ɪkspɛk mænɝz fɹəm ðɪs mæn?

Really, Vram," the woman said, "you expect manners from this man?

naʊ?"

Now?"

joʊli kwaɪətli ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd. ðə ɹum hɛld ə dʒʌmbəl ə fɝnɪtʃɝ: ə bɛɾ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum ðəɾ ɑbviəsli dɪdn bɪlɔŋ ðɛɹ, ə fju tʃɹʌŋks ən stændɪŋ wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz.

Yoeli quietly rested his hand on the hilt of his sword. The room held a jumble of furniture: a bed on the side of the room that obviously didn't belong there, a few trunks and standing wardrobes.

"soʊ," vɹæm sɛd, "ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi. jəɹ wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt kæptənz. aɪ ɹilaɪz ɪt maɪt bi ɪnsʌltɪŋ tə æsk, bʌɾ aɪ mʌst əbzɝv fɔɹmæləɾiz. jə ɹilaɪz ðət baɪ bɹɪŋɪŋ tʃɹups ɑntu əɹ sɔɪl, juv ɹɪskt ə wɔɹ?"

"So," Vram said, "Rodel Ituralde. You're one of the great captains. I realize it might be insulting to ask, but I must observe formalities. You realize that by bringing troops onto our soil, you have risked a war?"

"aɪ sɝv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "tɑɹmən ɡdən kʌmz ən ɔl pɹiviəs ælidʒiænsɪz, baʊndɝiz, ən lɔz ɑɹ sʌbʒɪkt tə ðə dʒɹæɡ-ɑnz wɪl."

"I serve the Dragon Reborn," Ituralde said. "Tarmon Gai'don comes and all previous allegiances, boundaries, and laws are subject to the Drag-on's will."

vɹæm klɪkt ɪz tʌŋ. "dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn. aɪ hæd ɹɪpɔɹts, ʌv kɔɹs - ən ðoʊz mɛn jə ɛmplɔɪ simd ən ɑbviəs hɪnt. bʌɾ ɪts stɪl soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ tə hɪɹ. dʒju nɑt ɹilaɪz haʊ ʌɾɝli fulɪʃ jə saʊnd?"

Vram clicked his tongue. "Dragonsworn. I had reports, of course - and those men you employ seemed an obvious hint. But it is still so strange to hear. Do you not realize how utterly foolish you sound?"

ɪɾɝɑldi mɛt ðə mænz aɪz. hi hædn kənsɪɾɝd hɪmsɛlf dʒɹæɡən-swɔɹn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus kɔlɪŋ ə hɔɹs ə ɹɑk ən ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls tə əɡɹi. "doʊn jə kɛɹ əbaʊt ði ɪnveɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks?"

Ituralde met the man's eyes. He hadn't considered himself Dragon-sworn, but there was no use calling a horse a rock and expecting everyone else to agree. "Don't you care about the invading Trollocs?"

"ðɛɹ əv bɪn tʃɹɑləks bɪfɔɹ," vɹæm sɛd. "ðɛɹ əv ɔlweɪz bɪn tʃɹɑləks."

"There have been Trollocs before," Vram said. "There have always been Trollocs."

"ðə kwin - " joʊli sɛd.

"The Queen - " Yoeli said.

"ðə kwin," vɹæm ɪntɝʌptɪd, "wɪl sun ɹɪtɝn fɹəm əɹ ɛkspədɪʃən tə ənmæsk ən kæptʃɝ ðɪs fɔls dʒɹæɡən. wʌns ðət hæpənz, ʃɪl si jə ɛksəkjuɾəd, tʃɹeɪɾɝ. ju, ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi, wɪl laɪkli bi spɛɹd kəz ə jəɹ steɪʃən, bʌɾ aɪ ʃəd nɑt laɪk tə bi jəɹ fæmli wən ðeɪ ɹəsiv ðə ɹænsəm dɪmænd. aɪ hoʊp ðət juv wɛlθ tə əkʌmpəni jəɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. ʌðɝwaɪz, jə ʃæl laɪkli spɛn mɛni ʌv ðə nɛks jɪɹz əz ə dʒɛnɝəl tə nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ðə ɹæts ə jəɹ sɛl."

"The Queen," Vram interrupted, "will soon return from her expedition to unmask and capture this false Dragon. Once that happens, she will see you executed, traitor. You, Rodel Ituralde, will likely be spared because of your station, but I should not like to be your family when they receive the ransom demand. I hope that you have wealth to accompany your reputation. Otherwise, you shall likely spend many of the next years as a general to nothing more than the rats of your cell."

"aɪ si," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "wɛn dɪd jə tɝn tə ðə ʃædoʊ?"

"I see," Ituralde said. "When did you turn to the Shadow?"

vɹæmz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən i stʊd. "ju dɛɹ neɪm mi dɑɹk-fɹɛnd?"

Vram's eyes opened wide, and he stood. "You dare name me Dark-friend?"

"aɪv noʊn səm sɑldəiənz ɪn maɪ taɪm," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "aɪv kɔl səm fɹɛnz; aɪv fɔɾ əɡɛnst ʌðɝz. bʌt nɛvɝ əv aɪ noʊn wʌn u wəd wɑtʃ mɛn faɪt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ən nɑɾ ɔfɝ tə hɛlp."

"I've known some Saldaeans in my time," Ituralde said. "I've called some friends; I've fought against others. But never have I known one who would watch men fight Shadowspawn and not offer to help."

"ɪf aɪ hæɾ ə sɔɹd . . ." vɹæm sɛd.

"If I had a sword . . ." Vram said.

"meɪ jə bɝn, vɹæm tɔɹkjəmɛn," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "aɪ keɪm hɪɹ tə tɛl jə ðət ðæt, ɑn bɪhæf ə ðə mɛn aɪ lɔst."

"May you burn, Vram Torkumen," Ituralde said. "I came here to tell you that that, on behalf of the men I lost."

ðə mæn simd ʃɑkt əz ɪɾɝɑldi tɝn tə ɡoʊ. joʊli dʒɔɪn hɪm, pʊlɪŋ ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd.

The man seemed shocked as Ituralde turned to go. Yoeli joined him, pulling the door closed.

"ju dɪsəɡɹi wɪð maɪ ækjəzeɪʃən?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝ əz ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə stɛɹz.

"You disagree with my accusation?" Ituralde asked, joining the traitor as they returned to the stairs.

"aɪ ɑnəsli kæn dɪsaɪɾ ɪf hiz ə ful əɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd," joʊli sɛd. "hiɾ əv tə bi wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ tə nɑt pʊt təɡɛðɝ ðə tʃɹuθ fɹəm ðə wɪntɝ, ðoʊz klaʊdz ən ðə ɹumɝz ðəɾ ælθɹ əz kɑŋkɝd hæf ðə wɝld."

"I honestly can't decide if he's a fool or a Darkfriend," Yoeli said. "He'd have to be one or the other to not put together the truth from the winter, those clouds and the rumors that al'Thor has conquered half the world."

"ðɛn juv nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ju woʊn bi ɛksəkjuɾəd.

"Then you have nothing to fear," Ituralde said. "You won't be executed.

"aɪ kɪl maɪ kʌntʃɹimɪn," joʊli sɛd, "steɪdʒd ə ɹɪvoʊlt əɡɛns maɪ kwinz əpɔɪntəd liɾɝ, ən siz kəmæn ə ðə sɪɾi, ðoʊ aɪv nɑɾ ə dʒɹɑp ə noʊbəl blʌd."

"I killed my countrymen," Yoeli said, "staged a revolt against my Queen's appointed leader, and seized command of the city, though I've not a drop of noble blood."

"ðæɾəl tʃeɪnʒ ðə moʊmən tɛnoʊbiə ɹɪtɝnz, aɪ wɔɹənt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "juv ɝn jɝsɛlf ə taɪɾəl fəɹ sɝɾən."

"That'll change the moment Tenobia returns, I warrant," Ituralde said. "You've earned yourself a title for certain."

joʊli stɑpt ɪn ðə dɑɹk stɛɹwɛl, lɪɾ oʊnli fɹəm əbʌv ən bɪloʊ. "aɪ si ðət jə də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. aɪ hæv bɪtʃɹeɪd maɪ oʊðz ən kɪl fɹɛnz. əl dɪmæn ɛksəkjuʃən, əz ɪz maɪ ɹaɪt."

Yoeli stopped in the dark stairwell, lit only from above and below. "I see that you do not understand. I have betrayed my oaths and killed friends. I will demand execution, as is my right."

ɪɾɝɑldi fɛlt ə tʃɪl. blʌɾi bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, hi θɔt. "swɛɹ jɝsɛlf tə ðə dʒɹæɡən. hi supɝsidz ɔl oʊðz. də nɑt weɪs jəɹ laɪf. faɪt bɪsaɪd mi ət ðə læs bæɾəl."

Ituralde felt a chill. Bloody Borderlanders, he thought. "Swear yourself to the Dragon. He supersedes all oaths. Do not waste your life. Fight beside me at the Last Battle."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt haɪd bɪhaɪn ɪkskjusɪz, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi," ðə mæn sɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ daʊn ðə stɛps. "noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪ kəd wɑtʃ jəɹ mɛn daɪ. kʌm. lɛɾ əs si tə ðə haʊzɪŋ ə ðoʊz æʃəmən. aɪ wəd laɪk vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə si ðiz ɡeɪtweɪz' jə spik ʌv. ɪf wi kəd juz əm tə sɛn mɛsədʒəz aʊɾ ən bɹɪŋ səplaɪz ɪn, ðɪs kəd bi ə vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ sidʒ ɪndid."

"I will not hide behind excuses, Lord Ituralde," the man said, continuing down the steps. "No more than I could watch your men die. Come. Let us see to the housing of those Asha'man. I would like very much to see these gateways' you speak of. If we could use them to send messages out and bring supplies in, this could be a very interesting siege indeed."

ɪɾɝɑldi saɪd, bʌt fɑloʊd. ðeɪ dɪdn spik ə fliɪŋ baɪ weɪ ʌv ðə ɡeɪtweɪz. joʊli wʊdn əbændən ɪz sɪɾi. ænd, hi ɹilaɪzd, ɪɾɝɑldi wʊdn əbændən joʊli ən ɪz mɛn. nɑɾ æftɝ wʌt ðeɪd ɡɔn θɹu tə ɹɛskju hɪm.

Ituralde sighed, but followed. They didn't speak of fleeing by way of the gateways. Yoeli wouldn't abandon his city. And, he realized, Ituralde wouldn't abandon Yoeli and his men. Not after what they'd gone through to rescue him.

ðɪs wɑz əz ɡʊɾ ə pleɪs əz ɛni tə meɪk ə stænd. bɛɾɝ ðən mɛni ə sɪtʃueɪʃən hid bɪn ɪn leɪtli, ðət wɑz fəɹ sɝɾən.

This was as good a place as any to make a stand. Better than many a situation he'd been in lately, that was for certain.

pɛɹɪn ɛntɝd ðɛɹ tɛn tə faɪn feɪl bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ. ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl. itʃ deɪ, hi stɪl fɛlt ə sɛns ʌv wʌndɝ ðət ʃi wɑz ɹɪli bæk.

Perrin entered their tent to find Faile brushing her hair. She was beautiful. Each day, he still felt a sense of wonder that she was really back.

ʃi tɝn tə hɪm ən smaɪld ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən. ʃi wɑz juzɪŋ ðə nu sɪlvɝ koʊm hid lɛft ɑn əɹ pɪloʊ - sʌmθɪŋ hid tʃɹeɪɾɪd fəɹ fɹəm ɡɔl, hu hæd faʊn ɪɾ ɪn meɪɾən. ɪf ðɪs ʃænəhɑɹ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ, ðən pɛɹɪn ɪntɛndəd tə tʃɹiɾ ɪt ðə seɪm weɪ.

She turned to him and smiled in satisfaction. She was using the new silver comb he'd left on her pillow - something he'd traded for from Gaul, who had found it in Maiden. If this shanna'har was important to her, then Perrin intended to treat it the same way.

"ðə mɛsənʒɝz əv ɹɪtɝnd," pɛɹɪn sɛd, kloʊzɪŋ ðə flæps tə ðə tɛnt. "ðə waɪtkloʊks əv tʃoʊzən ə bæɾəlfild. laɪt, feɪl. ðəɹ gɑnə fɔɹs mi tə waɪp əm aʊt."

"The messengers have returned," Perrin said, closing the flaps to the tent. "The Whitecloaks have chosen a battlefield. Light, Faile. They're going to force me to wipe them out."

"aɪ doʊn si ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ðæt," ʃi sɛd. "wil wɪn."

"I don't see the trouble with that," she said. "We'll win."

pɹɑbli," pɛɹɪn sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə pɪloʊz bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ slip- ɪŋ pælət. "bʌt dɪspaɪt ði æʃəmən duɪŋ moʊst ə ðə wɝk ət fɝst, wɪl əv tə muv ɪn tə faɪt. ðət minz wɪl luz pipəl. ɡʊd mɛn wi niɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl." hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə ɹɪlæks ðə fɪsts ðət hid klɛntʃt.

Probably," Perrin said, sitting down on the pillows beside their sleep- ing pallet. "But despite the Asha'man doing most of the work at first, we'll have to move in to fight. That means we'll lose people. Good men we need at the Last Battle." He forced himself to relax the fists that he'd clenched.

"ðə laɪt bɝn ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks fəɹ wʌt ðeɪv dʌn, ən fəɹ wʌt ðəɹ duɪŋ."

"The Light burn those Whitecloaks for what they've done, and for what they're doing."

"ðɛn ɪts ə wɛlkəm ɑpɝtunəɾi tə dɪfit ðɛm."

"Then it's a welcome opportunity to defeat them."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ ə ɹɪplaɪ, ən dɪdn ɪkspleɪn ðə dɛpθ ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən i fɛlt. hi wəd luz ðət faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə waɪtkloʊks, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt hæpənd. mɛn wəd daɪ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz. mɛn ðeɪ niɾəd.

Perrin grunted a reply, and didn't explain the depth of frustration he felt. He would lose that fight against the Whitecloaks, no matter what happened. Men would die on both sides. Men they needed.

ðə laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt aʊtsaɪd, kæstɪŋ ʃædoʊz ɑn ðə kænvəs sil-ɪŋ. feɪl wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðɛɹ tʃɹʌŋk, ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə slipɪŋ ʃɪft fəɹ hɝsɛlf ən sɛɾɪŋ əsaɪɾ ə ɹoʊb fəɹ hɪm. feɪl θɔɾ ə lɔɹd ʃəɾ əv ə ɹoʊb hændi ɪn keɪs i wɑz niɾəd ət naɪt. ʃid bɪn kɝɛkt ə kʌpəl ə taɪmz soʊ fɑɹ.

The lightning flashed outside, casting shadows on the canvas ceil-ing. Faile went over to their trunk, getting out a sleeping shift for herself and setting aside a robe for him. Faile thought a lord should have a robe handy in case he was needed at night. She'd been correct a couple of times so far.

ʃi muv pæs hɪm, smɛlɪŋ wɝid, ðoʊ hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz plɛzənt. hi hæɾ ɪkspɛndɪɾ ɔl ɑpʃənz fəɹ ə pisfəl ɹɛzəluʃən wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks. ɪt lʊk laɪk, wɑn ɪɾ əɹ nɑt, kɪlɪŋ wəd bi hɪz lɑɾ əɡɛn vɛɹi sun.

She moved past him, smelling worried, though her expression was pleasant. He had expended all options for a peaceful resolution with the Whitecloaks. It looked like, want it or not, killing would be his lot again very soon.

hi stʃɹɪp tə hɪz smɔlkloʊðz ən leɪ daʊn, ðən stɑɹɾəd dʒɹɪftɪŋ ɔf bɪfɔɹ feɪl hæd fɪnɪʃt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ.

He stripped to his smallclothes and lay down, then started drifting off before Faile had finished changing.

hi ɛntɝd ðə wʊlf dʒɹim bɪniθ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɔɹɾ ɪmpəlɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, hi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə hɪl ðət ɡɔl hæd neɪmd ə "faɪn wɑtʃpɔɪnt." ðə kæmpsaɪt wɑz səplaɪd fɹəm bɪhaɪn baɪ ə stʃɹim.

He entered the wolf dream beneath the great sword impaling the ground. In the distance, he could make out the hill that Gaul had named a "fine watchpoint." The campsite was supplied from behind by a stream.

pɛɹɪn tɝn ən spɛd təwɔɹd ðə waɪtkloʊk kæmp. ðeɪ sæt laɪk ə dæm ɪn ə ɹɪvɝ, stɑpɪŋ ɪm fɹəm kəntɪnjuɪŋ ɔnwɝd.

Perrin turned and sped toward the Whitecloak camp. They sat like a dam in a river, stopping him from continuing onward.

"hɑpɝ?" hi kɔld, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə waɪtkloʊk kæmp, stɪl tɛns stændɪŋ ɑn ən oʊpən fild.

"Hopper?" he called, looking around the Whitecloak camp, still tents standing on an open field.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹɪspɑns, soʊ pɛɹɪn sɝtʃt ðə kæmp ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ. beɪlwɝ hæd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə sil pɛɹɪn hæd dɪskɹaɪbd. hu lɛd ðiz waɪtkloʊks?

There was no response, so Perrin searched the camp a while longer. Balwer had not recognized the seal Perrin had described. Who led these Whitecloaks?

ən aʊɝ əɹ soʊ leɪɾɝ, pɛɹɪn hæd kʌm tə noʊ kənkluʒən əbaʊt ðæt. haʊɛvɝ, hi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən wɪtʃ tɛns ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ səplaɪz ɪn; ðoʊz maɪt nɑt bi əz wɛl ɡɑɹɾəd əz ðə pɹɪznɝz, ən - wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz - hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə bɝn ðɛɹ səplaɪz.

An hour or so later, Perrin had come to no conclusion about that. However, he was fairly certain which tents they kept their supplies in; those might not be as well guarded as the prisoners, and - with gateways - he might be able to burn their supplies.

meɪbi. ðɛɹ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝz lɛɾɝz wɝ fɪld wɪð fɹeɪzəz laɪk: "aɪ æm ɡɪvɪŋ jəɹ pipəl ðə bɛnəfɪɾ ə bɪlivɪŋ ðeɪ nu nɑɾ ə jəɹ neɪtʃɝ" ən "maɪ peɪʃəns fəɹ jəɹ dɪleɪz wɛɹz θɪn" ən "ðɛɹ ɑɹ oʊnli tu ɑpʃənz. sɝɛndɝ jɝsɛlf fəɹ pɹɑpɝ tʃɹaɪəl, əɹ bɹɪŋ jəɹ ɑɹmi tə sʌfɝ ðə laɪts dʒʌdʒmənt."

Maybe. Their Lord Captain Commander's letters were filled with phrases like: "I am giving your people the benefit of believing they knew not of your nature" and "My patience for your delays wears thin" and "There are only two options. Surrender yourself for proper trial, or bring your army to suffer the Light's judgment."

ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɛns ʌv ɑnɝ tə ðɪs mæn, wʌn pɛɹɪn hæd sin hɪntəɾ ət wən hid mɛt ðə mæn, bʌt kəd sɛns ivən mɔɹ θɹu ðə lɛɾɝz. bʌɾ u wɑz hi? hi saɪn itʃ lɛɾɝ oʊnli "lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt."

There was a strange sense of honor to this man, one Perrin had seen hinted at when he'd met the man, but could sense even more through the letters. But who was he? He signed each letter only "Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light."

pɛɹɪn muvd aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. wɛɹ wɑz hɑpɝ? pɛɹɪn tʊk ɔf əɾ ə bɹɪsk ɹʌn. æftɝ ə fju moʊməns, hi muvd ɔf ɑntu ðə ɡɹæs. ði ɝθ wɑz soʊ sɑft, itʃ stɛp sim tə spɹɪŋ ɪz fʊt bæk ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ. hi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən θɔɾ i sɛnst sʌmθɪŋ tə ðə saʊθ. hi ɹæn təwɔɹɾ ɪt; hi wɪʃt tə ɡoʊ fæstɝ, soʊ hi dɪd. tʃɹiz ən hɪlz zɪpt pæst. ðə wʊlvz wɝ əwɛɹ ə hɪm. ɪt wɑz oʊk dænsɝz pæk, wɪð baʊnləs, spɑɹks, mɔɹnɪŋɡlaɪt, ən ʌðɝz. pɛɹɪn kəd fil əm sɛndɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ, dɪstənt wɪspɝz ʌv ɪmədʒəz ən sɛnt. pɛɹɪn muv fæstɝ, filɪŋ ðə wɪn bɪkʌm ə ɹɔɹ ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə wʊlvz bɪɡæn tə muv əweɪ fɑɹðɝ saʊθ. weɪt! hi sɛnt. / mʌs mit wɪð ju!

Perrin moved out onto the roadway. Where was Hopper? Perrin took off at a brisk run. After a few moments, he moved off onto the grass. The earth was so soft, each step seemed to spring his foot back up into the air. He reached out and thought he sensed something to the south. He ran toward it; he wished to go faster, so he did. Trees and hills zipped past. The wolves were aware of him. It was Oak Dancer's pack, with Boundless, Sparks, Morninglight, and others. Perrin could feel them sending to one another, distant whispers of images and scent. Perrin moved faster, feeling the wind become a roar around him. The wolves began to move away farther south. Wait! he sent. / must meet with you!

ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn oʊnli əmjuzmənt. sʌɾənli, ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾɪŋ ist, ən i pʊl tə ə stɑp, ðən tɝnd. hi ɹæn əz kwɪkli əz i nu haʊ, bʌt wən i ɡɑt nɪɹ, ðeɪ wɝ sʌɾənli ɛlswɛɹ.

They returned only amusement. Suddenly, they were heading east, and he pulled to a stop, then turned. He ran as quickly as he knew how, but when he got near, they were suddenly elsewhere.

ðeɪd ʃɪftəd, vænɪʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə saʊθ ən əpɪɹɪŋ nɔɹθ ə hɪm.

They'd shifted, vanishing from the south and appearing north of him.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, ən sʌɾənli hi wɑz ɑn ɔl fɔɹz. hɪz fɝ blu, hɪz maʊθ oʊpən əz i dæʃt tə ðə nɔɹθ, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪn ðə hɪsɪŋ wɪnd. bʌt ðə wʊlvz steɪɾ əhɛd, dɪstənt.

Perrin growled, and suddenly he was on all fours. His fur blew, his mouth open as he dashed to the north, drinking in the hissing wind. But the wolves stayed ahead, distant.

hi haʊld. ðeɪ sɛn bæk tɔns.

He howled. They sent back taunts.

hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf fæstɝ, lipɪŋ fɹəm hɪltɑp tə hɪltɑp, baʊndɪŋ oʊvɝ tʃɹiz, ðə ɡɹaʊn ə blɝ. ɪn moʊməns, ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst spɹæŋ ʌp tə hɪz lɛft, ən i pæst əlɔŋ əm ɪn ə ɹʌʃ.

He pushed himself faster, leaping from hilltop to hilltop, bounding over trees, the ground a blur. In moments, the Mountains of Mist sprang up to his left, and he passed along them in a rush.

ðə wʊlvz tɝn ist. waɪ kʊdn i kætʃ ðɛm? hi kəd smɛl əm əhɛd. jʌŋ bʊl haʊld ət ðɛm, bʌt ɡɑt noʊ ɹɪspɑns.

The wolves turned east. Why couldn't he catch them? He could smell them ahead. Young Bull howled at them, but got no response.

də nɑt kʌm tu stʃɹɔŋli, jʌŋ bʊl.

Do not come too strongly, Young Bull.

jʌŋ bʊl pʊl tə ə hɔlt ən ðə wɝld lɝtʃt ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə meɪn pæk kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn tə ði ist, bʌt hɑpɝ sæɾ ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz bɪsaɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ kɝvɪŋ stʃɹim. jʌŋ bʊl hæd bɪn hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ;

Young Bull pulled to a halt and the world lurched around him. The main pack continued on to the east, but Hopper sat on his haunches beside a large curving stream. Young Bull had been here before;

ɪt wɑz nɪɹ ðə dɛn ə hɪz saɪɹz. hi hæd tʃɹævəld əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪtsɛlf ɑn ðə bæk ʌv wʌn ə ðə hjumənz' floʊɾɪŋ tʃɹiz. hi -  noʊ. . . noʊ . . . ɹɪmɛmbɝ feɪl!

it was near the den of his sires. He had traveled along the river itself on the back of one of the humans' floating trees. He -  No. . . no . . . remember Faile!

hɪz fɝ bɪkeɪm kloʊðɪŋ ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɑn hænz ən niz. hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɑpɝ. "waɪ dɪd jə ɹʌn əweɪ?" pɛɹɪn dɪmændəd.

His fur became clothing and he found himself on hands and knees. He glared at Hopper. "Why did you run away?" Perrin demanded.

jə wɪʃ tə lɝn, hɑpɝ sɛnt. jə ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ skɪld. fæstɝ. jə stʃɹɛtʃ jəɹ lɛɡz ən ɹʌn.

You wish to learn, Hopper sent. You grow more skilled. Faster. You stretch your legs and run.

ðɪs ɪz ɡʊd.

This is good.

pɛɹɪn lʊk bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɪz spid. hid baʊndəd fɹəm hɪltɑp tə hɪltɑp. ɪt hæd bɪn wʌndɝfəl. "bʌɾ aɪ hæd tə bɪkʌm ðə wʊlf tə də ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn ðət θɹɛɾənd tə meɪk mi hɪɹ 'tu stʃɹɔŋli. wʌt jus ɪz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪf ɪt meɪks mi də θɪŋz juv fɔɹbɪɾən?"

Perrin looked back the way he had come, thinking of his speed. He'd bounded from hilltop to hilltop. It had been wonderful. "But I had to become the wolf to do that," Perrin said. "And that threatened to make me here 'too strongly. What use is training if it makes me do things you've forbidden?"

jə ɑɹ kwɪk tə bleɪm, jʌŋ bʊl. ə jʌŋ wʊlf haʊlɪŋ ən jæpɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə dɛn, meɪkɪŋ ə ɹækɪt. ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə θɪŋ ʌv wʊlvz.

You are quick to blame, Young Bull. A young wolf howling and yapping outside the den, making a racket. This is not a thing of wolves.

hɑpɝ wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ən aɪɛblɪŋk.

Hopper was gone in an eyeblink.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, lʊkɪŋ istwɝd, wɛɹ i sɛns ðə wʊlvz. hi tʊk ɔf æftɝ ðɛm, ɡoʊɪŋ mɔɹ kɔʃəsli. hi kʊdn əfɔɹd tə lɛt ðə wʊlf kənsum hɪm. hiɾ ɛn ʌp laɪk noʊm, tʃɹæpt ɪn ə keɪdʒ, hɪz hjumænɪɾi ɡɔn. waɪ wəd hɑpɝ ɛnkɝɪdʒ ɪm tə ðæt?

Perrin growled, looking eastward, where he sensed the wolves. He took off after them, going more cautiously. He couldn't afford to let the wolf consume him. He'd end up like Noam, trapped in a cage, his humanity gone. Why would Hopper encourage him to that?

ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə θɪŋ ʌv wʊlvz. hæɾ i mɛn ði ækjəzeɪʃənz, əɹ hæɾ i mɛnt wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə pɛɹɪn?

This is not a thing of wolves. Had he meant the accusations, or had he meant what was happening to Perrin?

ði ʌðɝz ɔl nu tə ɛn ðə hʌnt, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛn fɹəm ə dɪs-tæns. oʊnli jə hæd tə bi stɑpt.

The others all knew to end the hunt, Young Bull, Hopper sent from a dis-tance. Only you had to be stopped.

pɛɹɪn fɹoʊz, pʊlɪŋ tə ə hɔlt ɑn ðə bæŋk ə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðə hʌn fəɹ ðə waɪt stæɡ. hɑpɝ wɑz ðɛɹ, sʌɾənli, bɪsaɪd ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪð hɪm.

Perrin froze, pulling to a halt on the bank of the river. The hunt for the white stag. Hopper was there, suddenly, beside the river with him.

"ðɪs stɑɹɾəd wən aɪ bɪɡæn tə sɛns ðə wʊlvz," pɛɹɪn sɛnt. "ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə maɪsɛlf wɑz wɪð ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks."

"This started when I began to sense the wolves," Perrin sent. "The first time I lost control of myself was with those Whitecloaks."

hɑpɝ leɪ daʊn, ɹɛstɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ɪz pɔz. jə ɔfən ɑɹ hɪɹ tu stʃɹɔŋli, ðə wʊlf sɛnt. // ɪz wʌt jə du.

Hopper lay down, resting his head on his paws. You often are here too strongly, the wolf sent. // is what you do.

hɑpɝ hæd toʊld ɪm ðæt, ɔf ən ɑn, sɪns hid noʊn ðə wʊlf ən ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. bʌt sʌɾənli, pɛɹɪn sɔ ə nu minɪŋ tə ɪt. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt kʌmɪŋ tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ əbaʊt pɛɹɪn hɪmsɛlf.

Hopper had told him that, off and on, since he'd known the wolf and the wolf dream. But suddenly, Perrin saw a new meaning to it. It was about coming to the wolf dream, but it was also about Perrin himself.

hid bɪɡʌn tə bleɪm ðə wʊlvz fəɹ wʌɾ i dɪd, ðə weɪ hi wɑz wən faɪɾɪŋ, ðə weɪ hid bɪkʌm wən sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ feɪl. bʌt wɝ ðə wʊlvz ðə kɑz ə ðæt? əɹ wɑz ɪt səm pɑɹɾ ə hɪm?

He'd begun to blame the wolves for what he did, the way he was when fighting, the way he'd become when searching for Faile. But were the wolves the cause of that? Or was it some part of him?

wɑz ɪt pɑsəbəl ðət ðət wɑz wʌt kɑzd ɪm tə bɪkʌm ə wʊlfbɹəðɝ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs?

Was it possible that that was what caused him to become a wolfbrother in the first place?

"ɪz ɪt pɑsəbəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "tə ɹʌn ɑn fɔɹ lɛɡz, bʌt nɑt kʌm hɪɹ tu stʃɹɔŋli?"

"Is it possible," Perrin said, "to run on four legs, but not come here too strongly?"

ʌv kɔɹs ɪɾ ɪz, hɑpɝ sɛnt, læfɪŋ æftɝ ðə weɪ ʌv wʊlvz - əz ɪf wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd dɪskʌvɝd wɑz ðə moʊst ɑbviəs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. meɪbi ɪt wɑz.

Of course it is, Hopper sent, laughing after the way of wolves - as if what Perrin had discovered was the most obvious thing in the world. Maybe it was.

pɝhæps i wɑzn laɪk ðə wʊlvz kəz i wɑz ə wʊlfbɹəðɝ. pɝhæps i wɑz ə wʊlfbɹəðɝ kəz i wɑz laɪk ðə wʊlvz. hi dɪdnt nid tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛm. hi niɾəd tə kəntʃɹoʊl hɪmsɛlf.

Perhaps he wasn't like the wolves because he was a wolfbrother. Perhaps he was a wolfbrother because he was like the wolves. He didn't need to control them. He needed to control himself.

"ðə pæk," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "haʊ də aɪ kætʃ ðɛm? muv mɔɹ kwɪkli?

"The pack," Perrin said. "How do I catch them? Move more quickly?

ðəɾ ɪz wʌn weɪ. ənʌðɝ ɪz tə bi wɛɹ jə wɑnt.

That is one way. Another is to be where you want.

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. ðən i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən juz ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə wʊlvz wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ɡɛs wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd bi. sʌmθɪŋ ʃɪftəd.

Perrin frowned. Then he closed his eyes and used the direction the wolves were running to guess where they would be. Something shifted.

wən i oʊpən ɪz aɪz, hi wɑz stændɪŋ ɑn ə sændi hɪlsaɪd, tʌfs ə lɔŋ-bleɪɾɪd ɡɹæs pikɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sɔɪl. ən ɪnɔɹməs maʊntən wɪð ə bɹoʊkən tɪp - ʃæɾɝd əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn slæp baɪ ðə hæn ʌv ə dʒaɪənt- -  ɹoʊz tə hɪz ɹaɪt.

When he opened his eyes, he was standing on a sandy hillside, tufts of long-bladed grass peeking out of the soil. An enormous mountain with a broken tip - shattered as if it had been slapped by the hand of a giant- -  rose to his right.

ə pæk ʌv wʊlvz bɝst aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst. mɛni ʌv əm wɝ læfɪŋ-jʌŋ bʊl, hʌntɪŋ wən i ʃəd sik ði ɛnd! jʌŋ bʊl, sikɪŋ ði ɛnd wən i ʃəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ðə hʌnt! hi smaɪld, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fil ɡʊd kæptʃɝɾ əbaʊt ðə læftɝ, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ i fɛl mʌtʃ əz i hæɾ ɑn ðə deɪ ðəɾ ɪz kʌzən wɪl hæd plæntəɾ ə bʌkəɾ ʌv wɛt fɛðɝz tə dʒɹɑp ɑn pɛɹɪn.

A pack of wolves burst out of the forest. Many of them were laughing-Young Bull, hunting when he should seek the end! Young Bull, seeking the end when he should enjoy the hunt! He smiled, trying to feel good captured about the laughter, though in truth he felt much as he had on the day that his cousin Wil had planted a bucket of wet feathers to drop on Perrin.

sʌmθɪŋ flʌɾɝd ɪn ði ɛɹ. ə tʃɪkən fɛðɝ. wɛɾ ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒəz.

Something fluttered in the air. A chicken feather. Wet around the edges.

pɛɹɪn stɑɹɾəd, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ spɹɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. əz i blɪŋkt, ðeɪ vænɪʃt. ðə wʊlvz smɛld ɡɹeɪtli əmjuzd, sɛndɪŋ aɪm- eɪdʒəz ə jʌŋ bʊl dʌstɪd wɪð fɛðɝz.

Perrin started, realizing that they were spread around him on the ground. As he blinked, they vanished. The wolves smelled greatly amused, sending im- ages of Young Bull dusted with feathers.

ɡɛt lɔst ɪn dʒɹimz hɪɹ, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt, ən ðoʊz dʒɹimz bɪkʌm ðɪs dʒɹim.

Get lost in dreams here, Young Bull, Hopper sent, and those dreams become this dream.

pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ɪz bɪɹd, faɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. hiɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns bɪfɔɹ ði ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl neɪtʃɝ ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. "hɑpɝ," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə ðə wʊlf. "haʊ mʌtʃ kəɾ aɪ tʃeɪnʒ əbaʊt maɪ sɝaʊndɪŋz, ɪf aɪ wɑntəd?"

Perrin scratched his beard, fighting down his embarrassment. He'd experienced before the unpredictable nature of the wolf dream. "Hopper," he said, turning to the wolf. "How much could I change about my surroundings, if I wanted?"

ɪf jə wɑntəd? hɑpɝ sɛd. ɪts nɑɾ əbaʊt wʌt jə wɑnt, jʌŋ bʊl. ɪts əbaʊt wʌt jə nid.

If you wanted? Hopper said. It's not about what you want, Young Bull. It's about what you need.

wʌt jə noʊ.

What you know.

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. səmtaɪmz ðə wʊlfs minɪŋz stɪl kənfjuz hɪm.

Perrin frowned. Sometimes the wolf's meanings still confused him.

sʌɾənli, ði ʌðɝ wʊlvz ɪn ðə ɡɹup tɝnd - əz ɪf wʌn - ən lʊk tə ðə saʊθwɛst. ðeɪ vænɪʃt.

Suddenly, the other wolves in the group turned - as if one - and looked to the southwest. They vanished.

ðeɪ wɛn hɪɹ. hɑpɝ sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ə dɪstənt wʊɾɪd hɑloʊ. ðə wʊlf pɹipɛɹd tə fɑloʊ.

They went here. Hopper sent an image of a distant wooded hollow. The wolf prepared to follow.

"hɑpɝ!" pɛɹɪn sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. "haʊ dɪd jə noʊ? wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt? dɪd ðeɪ tɛl ju?"

"Hopper!" Perrin said, stepping forward. "How did you know? Where they went? Did they tell you?"

noʊ. bʌɾ aɪ kən fɑloʊ.

No. But I can follow.

"haʊ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"How?" Perrin said.

ɪts ə θɪŋ aɪv ɔlweɪz noʊn, hɑpɝ sɛnt. laɪk wɔkɪŋ. əɹ dʒʌmpɪŋ.

It is a thing I've always known, Hopper sent. Like walking. Or jumping.

"jɛs, bʌt haʊ?"

"Yes, but how?"

ðə wʊlf smɛl kənfjuzd. ɪts ə sɛnt, hi faɪnəli ɹɪplaɪd, ðoʊ sɛnt" wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmplɛks ðən ðæt. ɪt wɑz ə filɪŋ, ən ɪmpɹɛʃən, ən ə smɛl ɔl ɪn wʌn.

The wolf smelled confused. It is a scent, he finally replied, though scent" was much more complex than that. It was a feeling, an impression, and a smell all in one.

"ɡoʊ sʌmwɛɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "lɛt mi tʃɹaɪ tə fɑloʊ."

"Go somewhere," Perrin said. "Let me try to follow."

hɑpɝ vænɪʃt. pɛɹɪn wɔkt ʌp tə wɛɹ ðə wʊlf hæd bɪn.

Hopper vanished. Perrin walked up to where the wolf had been.

smɛl ɪt, hɑpɝ sɛn dɪstənli. hi wɑz nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ə sɛndɪŋ, baɪ ɹiflɛks, pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt aʊt. hi faʊn dʌzənz ʌv wʊlvz. ɪn fækt, hi wɑz əmeɪz baɪ haʊ mɛni ʌv əm wɝ hɪɹ, ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. pɛɹɪn hæd nɛvɝ fɛl soʊ mɛni ɡæðɝɾ ɪn wʌn pleɪs bɪfɔɹ. waɪ wɝ ðeɪ hɪɹ? ən dɪd ðə skaɪ lʊk mɔɹ stɔɹmi ɪn ðɪs pleɪs ðən ɪt hæɾ ɪn ʌðɝ ɛɹiəz ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim?

Smell it, Hopper sent distantly. He was near enough to give a sending, By reflex, Perrin reached out. He found dozens of wolves. In fact, he was amazed by how many of them were here, on the slopes of Dragonmount. Perrin had never felt so many gathered in one place before. Why were they here? And did the sky look more stormy in this place than it had in other areas of the wolf dream?

hi kʊdn sɛns hɑpɝ; ðə wʊlf hæd kloʊz hɪmsɛlf ɔf, sʌmhaʊ, meɪkɪŋ pɛɹɪn əneɪbəl tə pleɪs wɛɹ i wɑz. pɛɹɪn sɛɾəld daʊn. smɛl ɪt, hɑpɝ hæd sɛnt. smɛl ɪt haʊ? pɛɹɪn kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən lɛɾ ɪz noʊz kætʃɹi ðə sɛns ə ði ɛɹiə tə hɪm. paɪn koʊnz ən sæp, kwɪlz ən livz, lɛðɝ-lif ən hɛmlɑk.

He couldn't sense Hopper; the wolf had closed himself off, somehow, making Perrin unable to place where he was. Perrin settled down. Smell it, Hopper had sent. Smell it how? Perrin closed his eyes and let his nose catry the scents of the area to him. Pine cones and sap, quills and leaves, leather-leaf and hemlock.

ən . . . sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. jɛs, hi kəd smɛl sʌmθɪŋ. ə dɪstənt, lɪn-ɡɪɹɪŋ sɛn ðət simd aʊɾ ə pleɪs. mɛni ʌv ðə sɛns wɝ ðə seɪm-ðə seɪm fɛkən sɛns ə neɪtʃɝ, ðə seɪm wɛlθ ə tʃɹiz.

And . . . something else. Yes, he could smell something. A distant, lin-gering scent that seemed out of place. Many of the scents were the same-the same fecund sense of nature, the same wealth of trees.

bʌt ðoʊz wɝ mɪkst wɪð ðə sɛns ə mɔs ən ʌv wɛt stoʊn. ði ɛɹ wɑz dɪfɹənt. pɔl-lɛn ən flaʊɝz.

But those were mixed with the scents of moss and of wet stone. The air was different. Pol-len and flowers.

pɛɹɪn skwizd ɪz aɪz taɪt, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn dipli. sʌmhaʊ, hi bɪlt ə pɪktʃɝ ɪn ɪz maɪn fɹəm ðoʊz sɛns. ðə pɹɑsɛs wɑz nɑɾ ənlaɪk ðə weɪ ə wʊlf sɛndɪŋ tʃɹænzleɪɾəd ɪndə wɝdz.

Perrin squeezed his eyes tight, breathing in deeply. Somehow, he built a picture in his mind from those scents. The process was not unlike the way a wolf sending translated into words.

ðɛɹ, hi θɔt. sʌmθɪŋ ʃɪftəd.

There, he thought. Something shifted.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. hi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ əmɪd paɪnz; hi wɑz ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, sɛvɹəl aʊɝz' haɪk ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd bɪn. ðə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ wɑz kʌvɝɾ ɪn laɪkən, ən ɪt dʒʌɾɪd aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹiz spɹɛɾɪŋ bɪloʊ. ə pætʃ ə vaɪəlɪt spɹɪŋbɹθ ɡɹu hɪɹ, wɛɹ sʌnlaɪt kəd ɹitʃ ðə blɑsəmz. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si flaʊɝz ðət wɝnt wɪltɪɾ əɹ daɪɪŋ, ɪf oʊnli ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

He opened his eyes. He was sitting on a stone outcropping amid pines; he was on the side of Dragonmount, several hours' hike up from where he had been. The stone outcropping was covered in lichen, and it jutted out over the trees spreading below. A patch of violet springbreath grew here, where sunlight could reach the blossoms. It was good to see flowers that weren't wilted or dying, if only in the wolf dream.

kʌm, hɑpɝ sɛnt. fɑloʊ.

Come, Hopper sent. Follow.

ən i wɑz ɡɔn.

And he was gone.

pɛɹɪn kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn. ðə pɹɑsɛs wɑz iziɝ ðɪs taɪm. oʊk ən ɡɹæs, mʌɾ ən hjumɪɾəti. ɪt simd itʃ pleɪs hæɾ ɪts oʊn spəsɪfɪk sɛnt.

Perrin closed his eyes, breathing in. The process was easier this time. Oak and grass, mud and humidity. It seemed each place had its own specific scent.

pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəd, ðən oʊpən ɪz aɪz. hi kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ə fil nɪɹ ðə dʒi-hænə ɹoʊd. ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ oʊk dænsɝz pæk hæd ɡɔn ɝliɝ, ən hɑpɝ muvd əbaʊt ðə mɛdoʊ, smɛlɪŋ kjʊɹiəs.

Perrin shifted, then opened his eyes. He crouched in a field near the Je-hannah Road. This was where Oak Dancer's pack had gone earlier, and Hopper moved about the meadow, smelling curious.

ðə pæk hæd muvd ɑn, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl kloʊz.

The pack had moved on, but they were still close.

"kæn aɪ ɔlweɪz də ðæt?" pɛɹɪn æsk hɑpɝ. "smɛl wɛɹ ə wʊlf wɛn ɪn ðə dʒɹim?"

"Can I always do that?" Perrin asked Hopper. "Smell where a wolf went in the dream?"

ɛniwʌn kæn, hɑpɝ sɛd. ɪf ðeɪ kən smɛl əz ə wʊlf dʌz. hi ɡɹɪnd.

Anyone can, Hopper said. If they can smell as a wolf does. He grinned.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd θɔtfəli.

Perrin nodded thoughtfully.

hɑpɝ loʊp bæk əkɹɔs ðə mɛdoʊ təwɔɹd hɪm. wi mʌs pɹæktəs, jʌŋ bʊl jə ɑɹ stɪl ə kʌb wɪð ʃɔɹt lɛɡz ən sɑft fɝ. wi -  hɑpɝ fɹoʊz sʌɾənli.

Hopper loped back across the meadow toward him. We must practice, Young Bull You are still a cub with short legs and soft fur. We -  Hopper froze suddenly.

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What?" Perrin asked.

ə wʊlf sʌɾənli haʊld ɪn peɪn. pɛɹɪn spʌn. ɪt wɑz mɔɹnɪŋɡlaɪt. ðə haʊl kʌɾ ɔf, ən ðə wʊlfs maɪnd wɪŋkt aʊt, vænɪʃɪŋ.

A wolf suddenly howled in pain. Perrin spun. It was Morninglight. The howl cut off, and the wolf's mind winked out, vanishing.

hɑpɝ ɡɹaʊld, hɪz sɛns pænɪkt, æŋɡɹi, ən sɑɹoʊfəl.

Hopper growled, his scents panicked, angry, and sorrowful.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" pɛɹɪn dɪmændəd.

"What was that?" Perrin demanded.

wəɹ hʌntəd. ɡoʊ, jʌŋ bʊl! wi mʌst ɡoʊ.

We are hunted. Go, Young Bull! We must go.

ðə maɪnz ə ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə pæk lɛpt əweɪ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld. wən ə wʊlf daɪɾ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, ɪt wɑz fɝɛvɝ. noʊ ɹibɝθ, noʊ ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð noʊz tə ðə wɪnd. oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ hʌntəd ðə spɪɹəts ə ðə wʊlvz. sleɪɝ.

The minds of the other members of the pack leaped away. Perrin growled. When a wolf died in the wolf dream, it was forever. No rebirth, no running with nose to the wind. Only one thing hunted the spirits of the wolves. Slayer.

jʌŋ bʊl! hɑpɝ sɛnt. wi mʌst ɡoʊ!

Young Bull! Hopper sent. We must go!

pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə ɡɹaʊl. mɔɹnɪŋɡlaɪt hæd sɛnt wʌn læs bɝst ə supɹaɪz ən peɪn, hɝ læs vɪʒən ə ðə wɝld. pɛɹɪn fɔɹmd ən ɪmədʒ fɹəm ðət dʒʌmbəl. ðən kloʊzd ɪz aɪz.

Perrin continued to growl. Morninglight had sent one last burst of suprise and pain, her last vision of the world. Perrin formed an image from that jumble. Then closed his eyes.

jʌŋ bʊl! noʊ! hi -  ʃɪft. pɛɹɪn snæpt ɪz aɪz oʊpən tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə smɔl ɡleɪd nɪɹ wɛɹ - ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld - hɪz pipəl meɪd kæmp. ə mʌskjəlɝ, tæn mæn wɪð dɑɹk hɛɹ ən blu aɪz skwɑɾɪd ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɡleɪd, ə wʊlfs kɔɹps əɾ ɪz fit.

Young Bull! No! He -  Shift. Perrin snapped his eyes open to find himself in a small glade near where - in the real world - his people made camp. A muscular, tanned man with dark hair and blue eyes squatted in the center of the glade, a wolf's corpse at his feet.

sleɪɝ wɑz ə θɪk-ɑɹmd mæn, ən ɪz sɛnt wɑz feɪnli ɪnhjumən, laɪk ə mæn mɪkst wɪð stoʊn. hi wɔɹ dɑɹk kloʊðɪŋ; lɛðɝ ən blæk wʊl. əz pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt, sleɪɝ bɪɡæn tə skɪn ðə kɔɹps.

Slayer was a thick-armed man, and his scent was faintly inhuman, like a man mixed with stone. He wore dark clothing; leather and black wool. As Perrin watched, Slayer began to skin the corpse.

pɛɹɪn tʃɑɹdʒ fɔɹwɝd. sleɪɝ lʊkt ʌp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. hi ɹɪzɛmbəld læn ɪn ən ɔlmoʊst ɪɹi fæʃən, hɪz hɑɹd feɪs ɔl æŋɡəlz ən ʃɑɹp laɪnz. pɛɹɪn ɹɔɹd, hæmɝ sʌɾənli ɪn ɪz hænz.

Perrin charged forward. Slayer looked up in surprise. He resembled Lan in an almost eerie fashion, his hard face all angles and sharp lines. Perrin roared, hammer suddenly in his hands.

sleɪɝ vænɪʃt ɪn ə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ, ən pɛɹɪnz hæmɝ pæs θɹu ɛmpti ɛɹ. pɛɹɪn bɹið dipli. ðə sɛns wɝ ðɛɹ! bɹaɪn, ən wʊd, wɛt wɪð wɔɾɝ. siɡulz ən ðɛɹ dʒɹɑpɪŋz. pɛɹɪn juzd ɪz nufaʊn skɪl tə hɝl hɪmsɛlf ət ðət dɪstən loʊkeɪʃən.

Slayer vanished in a blink of an eye, and Perrin's hammer passed through empty air. Perrin breathed deeply. The scents were there! Brine, and wood, wet with water. Seagulls and their droppings. Perrin used his newfound skill to hurl himself at that distant location.

ʃɪft.

Shift.

pɛɹɪn əpɪɹɾ ɑn ən ɛmpti dɑk ɪn ə sɪɾi hi dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. sleɪɝ stʊd nɪɹbaɪ, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ɪz baʊ.

Perrin appeared on an empty dock in a city he didn't recognize. Slayer stood nearby, inspecting his bow.

pɛɹɪn ətækt. sleɪɝ bɹɔɾ ɪz hɛɾ ʌp, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ, hɪz sɛnt ɡɹoʊɪŋ əmeɪzd. hi ɹeɪz ðə baʊ tə blɑk, bʌt pɛɹɪnz swɪŋ ʃæɾɝd ɪt.

Perrin attacked. Slayer brought his head up, eyes widening, his scent growing amazed. He raised the bow to block, but Perrin's swing shattered it.

wɪð ə ɹɔɹ, pɛɹɪn pʊld ɪz wɛpən bæk ən swʌŋ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm fəɹ sleɪɝz hɛd. ɑdli, sleɪɝ smaɪld, dɑɹk aɪz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ wɪð əmjuzmənt. hi smɛld iɡɝ, sʌɾənli. iɡɝ tə kɪl. ə sɔɹɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪz ɹeɪz hænd, ən i twɪstəɾ ɪt tə blɑk pɛɹɪnz bloʊ.

With a roar, Perrin pulled his weapon back and swung again, this time for Slayer's head. Oddly, Slayer smiled, dark eyes glittering with amusement. He smelled eager, suddenly. Eager to kill. A sword appeared in his raised hand, and he twisted it to block Perrin's blow.

ðə hæmɝ baʊnst ɔf tu hɑɹd, əz ɪf ɪt hæd hɪt stoʊn. pɛɹɪn stʌmbəld, ən sleɪɝ ɹitʃt aʊt, pleɪsɪŋ ə hæn əɡɛns pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. hi ʃʌvd.

The hammer bounced off too hard, as if it had hit stone. Perrin stumbled, and Slayer reached out, placing a hand against Perrin's shoulder. He shoved.

hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz ɪmɛns. ðə ʃʌv tɔs pɛɹɪn bækwɝd tə ðə dɑk, bʌt ðə wʊd dɪsəpɪɹɾ əz i hɪt. pɛɹɪn pæs θɹu ɛmpti ɛɹ ən splæʃt ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ bɪniθ. hɪz bɛloʊ bɪkeɪm ə ɡɝɡəl; dɑɹk lɪkwəd sɝaʊndəd hɪm.

His strength was immense. The shove tossed Perrin backward to the dock, but the wood disappeared as he hit. Perrin passed through empty air and splashed into the water beneath. His bellow became a gurgle; dark liquid surrounded him.

hi stʃɹʌɡəl tə swɪm ʌpwɝd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ, bʌt faʊn ðət ðə sɝfəs ɪnɪksplɪkəbli bɪkeɪm aɪs. ɹoʊps sneɪkt ʌp fɹəm ðə dɛpθs, wɪpɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmz, jæŋkɪŋ ɪm daʊnwɝd. θɹu ðə fɹoʊzən sɝfəs əbʌv, hi kəd si ə ʃædoʊ muvɪŋ. sleɪɝ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪ- fɔɹm baʊ.

He struggled to swim upward, dropping his hammer, but found that the surface inexplicably became ice. Ropes snaked up from the depths, whipping up around Perrin's arms, yanking him downward. Through the frozen surface above, he could see a shadow moving. Slayer, raising his re- formed bow.

ði aɪs vænɪʃt ən ðə wɔɾɝ pɑɹɾəd. wɔɾɝ stʃɹimd ɔf pɛɹɪn, ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ æɹoʊ pɔɪntəd dɝɛkli əɾ ɪz hɑɹt.

The ice vanished and the water parted. Water streamed off Perrin, and he found himself staring up at arrow pointed directly at his heart.

sleɪɝ ɹilist.

Slayer released.

pɛɹɪn wɪl hɪmsɛlf əweɪ.

Perrin willed himself away.

ʃɪft. hi ɡæspt, hɪɾɪŋ ðə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ wɛɹ i hæd bɪn wɪð hɑpɝ. pɛɹɪn fɛl tə hɪz niz, siwɑɾɝ stʃɹimɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bɑɾi hi spʌɾɝd, waɪpɪŋ ɪz feɪs, hɑɹt paʊndɪŋ.

Shift. He gasped, hitting the stone outcropping where he had been with Hopper. Perrin fell to his knees, seawater streaming from his body He sputtered, wiping his face, heart pounding.

hɑpɝ əpɪɹd bɪsaɪd hɪm, pæntɪŋ, hɪz sɛn æŋɡɹi. fulɪʃ kʌb! stupəd kʌb! tʃeɪs daʊn ə laɪən wən jəɹ bɛɹli wind?

Hopper appeared beside him, panting, his scent angry. Foolish cub! Stupid cub! Chase down a lion when you're barely weaned?

pɛɹɪn ʃɪvɝɾ ən sæɾ ʌp. wəd sleɪɝ fɑloʊ? kəd hi? əz mɪnəts stʃɹɛtʃt ən noʊbɑdi əpɪɹd, pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə ɹɪlæks. ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ wɪð sleɪɝ hæd hæpən soʊ kwɪkli ðəɾ ɪt fɛlt laɪk ə blɝ. ðət stʃɹɛŋkθ ... ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɛni mæn kəd hæv. ən ði aɪs, ðə ɹoʊps . . .

Perrin shivered and sat up. Would Slayer follow? Could he? As minutes stretched and nobody appeared, Perrin began to relax. The exchange with Slayer had happened so quickly that it felt like a blur. That strength ... it was more than any man could have. And the ice, the ropes . . .

"hi tʃeɪnʒd θɪŋz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "meɪd ðə dɑk vænɪʃ bɪniθ mi, kɹieɪɾəd ɹoʊps tə baɪn mi, pʊʃt ðə wɔɾɝ bæk soʊ ðəɾ i kəd ɡɛɾ ə klɪɹ ʃɑɾ ət mi."

"He changed things," Perrin said. "Made the dock vanish beneath me, created ropes to bind me, pushed the water back so that he could get a clear shot at me."

hiz ə laɪən. hi kɪlz. deɪnʒɝəs.

He is a lion. He kills. Dangerous.

"aɪ nid tə lɝn. aɪ mʌs feɪs hɪm, hɑpɝ."

"I need to learn. I must face him, Hopper."

jə ɑɹ tu jʌŋ. ðiz θɪŋz ɑɹ bɪɑn ju.

You are too young. These things are beyond you.

"tu jʌŋ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd, stændɪŋ. "hɑpɝ, ðə læs hʌn ɪz nɪɹli əpɑn ʌs!"

"Too young?" Perrin said, standing. "Hopper, the Last Hunt is nearly upon us!"

hɑpɝ leɪ daʊn, hɛɾ ɑn pɔz.

Hopper lay down, head on paws.

"ju ɔlweɪz tɛl mi ðəɾ aɪm tu jʌŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɔɹ ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ. wɛl, wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɔɪn ə titʃɪŋ mi, ɪf nɑt tə ʃoʊ mi haʊ tə faɪt mɛn laɪk sleɪɝ?"

"You always tell me that I'm too young," Perrin said. "Or that I don't know what I'm doing. Well, what is the point of teaching me, if not to show me how to fight men like Slayer?"

wɪl si, hɑpɝ sɛnt. fəɹ tənaɪt, jəl ɡoʊ. wəɹ dʌn.

We will see, Hopper sent. For tonight, you will go. We are done.

pɛɹɪn sɛnst ə mɔɹnfəl kæs tə ðə sɛndɪŋ, ən ɔlsoʊ ə faɪnæləɾi. tənaɪt, oʊk dænsɝz pæk ən hɑpɝ wəd ɡɹiv fəɹ mɔɹnɪŋɡlaɪt.

Perrin sensed a mournful cast to the sending, and also a finality. Tonight, Oak Dancer's pack and Hopper would grieve for Morninglight.

saɪɪŋ, pɛɹɪn sæt wɪð ɪz lɛɡz kɹɔst. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd, ən mænədʒ tə ɪməteɪt ðə θɪŋz ðət hɑpɝ hæd dʌn ɪn tɔsɪŋ ɪm fɹəm ðə dʒɹim.

Sighing, Perrin sat with his legs crossed. He concentrated, and managed to imitate the things that Hopper had done in tossing him from the dream.

ɪt feɪɾəd ɝaʊn hɪm.

It faded around him.

hi woʊk ɑn ðə pæləɾ ɪn ɪz dɑɹkən tɛnt, feɪl snʌɡəld ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm-pɛɹɪn leɪ fəɹ ə taɪm, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə kænvəs. ðə dɑɹknəs ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə ðə tɛmpɛstʃuəs skaɪ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. slip simd əz fɑɹ ɔf əz keɪɛmlɪn- ɪvɛntʃəwəli hi ɹoʊz - kɛɹfəli ɪkstʃɹəkeɪɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɹəm feɪl -  ən pʊld ɑn ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ʃɝt.

He woke on the pallet in his darkened tent, Faile snuggled up beside him-Perrin lay for a time, staring up at the canvas. The darkness reminded him of the tempestuous sky in the wolf dream. Sleep seemed as far off as Caemlyn- Eventually he rose - carefully extricating himself from Faile -  and pulled on his trousers and shirt.

ðə kæmp wɑz dɑɹk aʊtsaɪd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf laɪt fəɹ ɪz aɪz. hi nɑɾəd tə kɛnli mɹɪn ən dʒeɪm dɔtʃɹi, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn u ɡɑɹɾəd ɪz tɛn tənaɪt.

The camp was dark outside, but there was enough light for his eyes. He nodded to Kenly Maerin and Jaim Dawtry, the Two Rivers men who guarded his tent tonight.

"wʌts ðə taɪm?" hi æskt wʌn ə ðɛm.

"What's the time?" he asked one of them.

"æftɝ mɪdnaɪt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," dʒeɪm sɛd.

"After midnight, Lord Perrin," Jaim said.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. dɪstən laɪtnɪŋ lɪt ðə lændskeɪp. hi wɔkt ɔf, ən ðə mɛn stɑɹɾəd tə fɑloʊ.

Perrin grunted. Distant lightning lit the landscape. He walked off, and the men started to follow.

"aɪl bi faɪn wɪθaʊt ɡɑɹdz," hi toʊl ðɛm. "wɑtʃ oʊvɝ maɪ tɛnt - leɪɾi feɪl stɪl slips."
