"I'll be fine without guards," he told them. "Watch over my tent - Lady Faile still sleeps."

hɪz tɛnt wɑz nɪɹ ði ɛdʒ ə kæmp. hi laɪk ðæt; ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ sɛns ə sɪkluʒən, nɛsəl nɪɹ ðə hɪlsaɪɾ ət ðə wɛstɝn saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp. ðoʊ ɪt wɑz leɪt, hi pæst ɡɔl ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ nɪɹ ə fɔlən lɔɡ. ðə tɔl stoʊn dɔɡ stʊɾ ʌp ən bɪɡæn tə fɑloʊ, ən pɛɹɪn dɪdn dɪsmɪs hɪm. ɡɔl fɛlt i hædn bɪn fʊlfɪlɪŋ ɪz sɛlf-əpɔɪntəd duɾi ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ æftɝ pɛɹɪn leɪtli, ən hæd stɛpt ʌp ɪz ɛfɝts. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i ɹɪli dʒʌst wɑntəɾ ən ɪkskjus tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɪz oʊn tɛn ən ðə pɛɹ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn wɪmən u hæd teɪkən ʌp ɹɛzəɾəns ðɛɹ.

His tent was near the edge of camp. He liked that; it gave him a little more sense of seclusion, nestled near the hillside at the western side of the camp. Though it was late, he passed Gaul sharpening his spear near a fallen log. The tall Stone Dog stood up and began to follow, and Perrin didn't dismiss him. Gaul felt he hadn't been fulfilling his self-appointed duty of watching after Perrin lately, and had stepped up his efforts. Perrin thought he really just wanted an excuse to stay away from his own tent and the pair of gai'shain women who had taken up residence there.

ɡɔl kɛpt ɪz dɪstəns, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz ɡlæd. wɑz ðɪs haʊ ɔl liɾɝz fɛlt? noʊ wʌndɝ soʊ mɛni neɪʃənz ɛndəɾ ʌp ət wɔɹ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ - ðɛɹ liɾɝz nɛvɝ hæɾ ɛni taɪm tə θɪŋk baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz, ən pɹɑbli ətæk tə ɡɛt pipəl tə stɑp pɛstɝɪŋ ðɛm!

Gaul kept his distance, and Perrin was glad. Was this how all leaders felt? No wonder so many nations ended up at war with one another - their leaders never had any time to think by themselves, and probably attacked to get people to stop pestering them!

ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, hi ɛntɝɾ ə stæn ə tʃɹiz wɪð ə smɔl paɪl ə lɔɡz. dɛntən - hɪz sɝvɪŋ mæn əntɪl ðeɪ ɡɑt læmɡwɪn bæk - hæd fɹaʊnd wən pɛɹɪn hæɾ æsk fəɹ ðɛm. wʌns ə maɪnɝ lɔɹɾ ə kɛɹhin, dɛntən hæd ɹəfjuz tə ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz steɪʃən. hi θɔɾ ə hɪmsɛlf əz ə sɝvənt naʊ, ən wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn kənvɪns ɪm ʌðɝwaɪz.

A short distance away, he entered a stand of trees with a small pile of logs. Denton - his serving man until they got Lamgwin back - had frowned when Perrin had asked for them. Once a minor lord of Cairhien, Denton had refused to return to his station. He thought of himself as a servant now, and would not let anyone convince him otherwise.

ðəɹ wɑz ən æks. nɑt ðə dɛdli hæf-mun bleɪɾ i hæd wʌns kæɹid tə bæɾəl, bʌɾ ə stɝɾi wʊdzmənz æks wɪð ə faɪn stil hɛɾ ən ə hæf smuð baɪ ðə swɛɾi hænz ʌv wɝkɝz. pɛɹɪn ɹoʊld ʌp ɪz slivz, ðən spæɾ ɑn ɪz hænz ən pɪkt ʌp ði æks. ɪt fɛlt ɡʊd tə hoʊl ðə wɝkt wʊɾ ɪn ɪz hænz. hi ɹeɪzd ɪt tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ, stʊd ðə fɝs lɔɡ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ðən stɛp bæk ən swʌŋ.

There was an axe. Not the deadly half-moon blade he had once carried to battle, but a sturdy woodsman's axe with a fine steel head and a haft smoothed by the sweaty hands of workers. Perrin rolled up his sleeves, then spat on his hands and picked up the axe. It felt good to hold the worked wood in his hands. He raised it to his shoulder, stood the first log in front of him, then stepped back and swung.

hi hɪt ðə lɔɡ stʃɹeɪɾ ɑn, splɪntɝz flɪpɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk naɪɾ ɛɹ, ðə lɔɡ ɹeɪlɪŋ ɪndə tu pisəz. hi splɪt wʌn ə ðə hævz nɛkst. ɡɔl tʊk ə sit bɪsaɪɾ ə tʃɹi, ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə spɪɹ ən kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə ʃɑɹpən ɪts hɛd. ðə ɹæspɪŋ ə mɛɾəl əɡɛns mɛɾəl əkʌmpənid pɛɹɪnz θʌŋk ʌv æks əɡɛnst wʊd.

He hit the log straight on, splinters flipping into the dark night air, the log railing into two pieces. He split one of the halves next. Gaul took a seat beside a tree, getting out a spear and continuing to sharpen its head. The rasping of metal against metal accompanied Perrin's thunk of axe against wood.

ɪt fɛlt ɡʊd. waɪ wɑz ɪt ðəɾ ɪz maɪnd wɝk soʊ mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ wən i wɑz duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ? lɔɪəl spoʊk mʌtʃ ə sɪɾɪŋ ən θɪŋkɪŋ. pɛɹɪn dɪdn θɪŋk i hɪmsɛlf kəd fɪɡjɝ ɛniθɪŋ aʊt ðət weɪ.

It felt good. Why was it that his mind worked so much better when he was doing something? Loial spoke much of sitting and thinking. Perrin didn't think he himself could figure anything out that way.

hi splɪɾ ənʌðɝ lɔɡ, ði æks kʌɾɪŋ klɪɹ. wɑz ɪt ɹɪli tʃɹu? kəɾ ɪz oʊn neɪtʃɝ bi tə bleɪm fəɹ ðə weɪ hi æktəd, nɑt ðə wʊlvz? hid nɛvɝ æktəd laɪk ðət bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

He split another log, the axe cutting clear. Was it really true? Could his own nature be to blame for the way he acted, not the wolves? He'd never acted like that back in the Two Rivers.

hi splɪɾ ənʌðɝ lɔɡ. / ɔlweɪz aɪvəz ɡʊɾ ət kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ maɪ ətɛnʃən. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt hæɾ ɪmpɹɛs mæstɝ luhən. ɡɪv pɛɹɪn ə pɹɑdʒɛkt ən hid kip wɝkɪŋ ɑn ɪɾ əntɪl i wɑz dʌn.

He split another log. / always ivas good at concentrating my attention. That was part of what had impressed Master Luhhan. Give Perrin a project and he'd keep working on it until he was done.

hi splɪt ðə hævz ə ðət lɔɡ.

He split the halves of that log.

meɪbi ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn ɪm wɝ ə ɹɪzʌlt ʌv ɛnkaʊntɝɪŋ ði aʊtsaɪd wɝld. hid bleɪm ðə wʊlvz fəɹ mɛni θɪŋz, ən i hæd pleɪst ənnætʃɹəl dɪmænz ɑn hɑpɝ. wʊlvz wɝn stupəɾ əɹ sɪmpəl, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊt θɪŋz ðət hjumənz dɪd. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn vɛɹi hɑɹd fəɹ hɑpɝ tə titʃ ɪn ə weɪ ðət pɛɹɪn wəɾ ʌndɝstænd.

Maybe the changes in him were a result of encountering the outside world. He'd blamed the wolves for many things, and he had placed unnatural demands on Hopper. Wolves weren't stupid or simple, but they did not care about things that humans did. It must have been very hard for Hopper to teach in a way that Perrin would understand.

wʌd ðə wʊlf oʊ hɪm? hɑpɝ hæd daɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðət feɪtfəl naɪt, soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðə naɪt wən pɛɹɪn hæd fɝs kɪld ə mæn, ðə naɪt pɛɹɪn hæd fɝs lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə bæɾəl. hɑpɝ dɪdn oʊ pɛɹɪn ɛniθɪŋ, bʌɾ i hæd seɪv pɛɹɪn ɑn sɛvɹəl əkeɪʒənz - ɪn fækt, pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪz ðət hɑpɝz ɪntɝvɛntʃən hæd hɛlp tə kip ɪm fɹəm luzɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əz ə wʊlf.

What did the wolf owe him? Hopper had died during that fateful night, so long ago. The night when Perrin had first killed a man, the night Perrin had first lost control of himself in a battle. Hopper didn't owe Perrin anything, but he had saved Perrin on several occasions - in fact, Perrin realized that Hopper's intervention had helped to keep him from losing himself as a wolf.

hi swʌŋ əɾ ə lɔɡ, ə ɡlænsɪŋ bloʊ ðət nɑkt ɪt tə ðə saɪd. hi ɹipəzɪʃən ən kəntɪnjud, ɡɔlz kwaɪət ʃɑɹpənɪŋ suðɪŋ hɪm. hi splɪɾ ɪt.

He swung at a log, a glancing blow that knocked it to the side. He repositioned and continued, Gaul's quiet sharpening soothing him. He split it.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹu kɑɾ ʌp ɪn wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, meɪbi tu mʌtʃ. ðət wɑz tʃɹu.

Perrin grew caught up in what he was doing, maybe too much. That was true.

bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɪf ə mæn wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ dʌn, hi hæd tə wɝk ɑn wʌn pɹɑdʒɛkt əntɪl ɪt wɑz kəmplit. pɛɹɪn hæd noʊn mɛn u nɛvɝ sim tə fɪnɪʃ ɛniθɪŋ, ən ðɛɹ fɑɹmz wɝ ə mɛs. hi kʊdn lɪv laɪk ðæt.

But at the same time, if a man wanted to get anything done, he had to work on one project until it was complete. Perrin had known men who never seemed to finish anything, and their farms were a mess. He couldn't live like that.

ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə bæləns. pɛɹɪn hæd kleɪmd i hæd bɪn pʊld ɪndə ə wɝl fɪld wɪð pɹɑbləmz mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən i wɑz. hi hæd kleɪmd i wɑz ə sɪmpəl mæn.

There had to be a balance. Perrin had claimed he had been pulled into a world filled with problems much larger than he was. He had claimed he was a simple man.

wʌɾ ɪf i wɑz ɹɔŋ? wʌɾ ɪf i wɑz ə kɑmplɛks mæn u hæd wʌns hæpən tə lɪv ə sɪmpəl laɪf? æftɝ ɔl, ɪf i wɑz soʊ sɪmpəl, waɪ hæɾ i fɔlən ɪn lʌv wɪð sətʃ ə kɑmpləkeɪɾəd wʊmən?

What if he was wrong? What if he was a complex man who had once happened to live a simple life? After all, if he was so simple, why had he fallen in love with such a complicated woman?

ðə splɪt lɔɡz wɝ paɪlɪŋ ʌp. pɛɹɪn bɛn daʊn, ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp kɔɹɾɝz, ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪn ɹʌf əɡɛnst ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. kælʌz fɪŋɡɝz; hi wəd nɛvɝ bi ə lɔɹd laɪk ðoʊz mɪlk-fɛd kɹitʃɝz fɹəm kɛɹhin.

The split logs were piling up. Perrin bent down, gathering up quarters, their grain rough against his fingers. Callused fingers; he would never be a lord like those milk-fed creatures from Cairhien.

bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ kaɪnz ə lɔɹdz, mɛn laɪk feɪlz oʊn fɑðɝ. əɹ mɛn laɪk læn, hu simd mɔɹ wɛpən ðən mæn.

But there were other kinds of lords, men like Faile's own father. Or men like Lan, who seemed more weapon than man.

pɛɹɪn stæk ðə wʊd. hi ɛndʒɔɪd liɾɪŋ ðə wʊlvz ɪn ɪz dʒɹim, bʌt wʊlvz dɪdn ɪkspɛk jə tə pɹətɛk ðɛm, əɹ tə pɹəvaɪd fəɹ ðɛm, əɹ tə meɪk lɔz fəɹ ðɛm. ðeɪ dɪdn kɹaɪ tə jə wən ðɛɹ lʌvd wʌnz daɪd bɪniθ jəɹ kəmænd.

Perrin stacked the wood. He enjoyed leading the wolves in his dream, but wolves didn't expect you to protect them, or to provide for them, or to make laws for them. They didn't cry to you when their loved ones died beneath your command.

ɪt wɑzn ðə liɾɝʃɪp ðət wɝid hɪm. ɪt wɑz ɔl ðə θɪŋz ðət keɪm wɪð ɪt.

It wasn't the leadership that worried him. It was all the things that came with it.

hi kəd smɛl ɛlaɪəs əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. wɪð ɪz loʊmi, nætʃɹəl ɝθən sɛn i smɛld laɪk ə wʊlf.

He could smell Elyas approaching. With his loamy, natural earthen scent he smelled like a wolf.

ɔlmoʊst.

Almost.

"jɔɹ ʌp leɪt," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp. pɛɹɪn hɝd ɡɔl ɹʌslɪŋ, slɪpɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ bæk ɪndə ɪts pleɪs ɑn ɪz boʊkeɪs, ðən wɪθdʒɹɔɪŋ wɪð ðə saɪləns ʌv ə spɛɹoʊ stʃɹikɪŋ ɔf ɪndə ðə skaɪ.

"You're up late," Elyas said, stepping up. Perrin heard Gaul rustling, slipping his spear back into its place on his bowcase, then withdrawing with the silence of a sparrow streaking off into the sky.

hi wəd steɪ kloʊs, bʌt wəd nɑt lɪsən ɪn.

He would stay close, but would not listen in.

pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ðə dɑɹk skaɪ, ɹɛstɪŋ ði æks ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "səmtaɪmz aɪ fil mɔɹ əweɪk ət naɪt ðən dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ."

Perrin looked up at the dark sky, resting the axe on his shoulder. "Sometimes I feel more awake at night than during the day."

ɛlaɪəs smaɪld. pɛɹɪn dɪdn si ɪt, bʌɾ i kəd smɛl ði əmjuzmənt.

Elyas smiled. Perrin didn't see it, but he could smell the amusement.

"dɪd jə ɛvɝ tʃɹaɪ tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt, ɛlaɪəs?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz, pɹitɛn ðət nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt jə hæd tʃeɪnʒd?"

"Did you ever try to avoid it, Elyas?" Perrin asked. "Ignore their voices, pretend that nothing about you had changed?"

"aɪ dɪd," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. hi hæɾ ə sɑf loʊ vɔɪs, wʌn ðət sʌmhaʊ sədʒɛstəd ði ɝθ ɪn moʊʃən.

"I did," Elyas said. He had a soft low voice, one that somehow suggested the earth in motion.

dɪstən ɹʌmbəlz. "aɪ wɑntəd tə, bʌt ðən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəd tə dʒɛntəl mi. aɪ hæd tə fli."

Distant rumbles. "I wanted to, but then the Aes Sedai wanted to gentle me. I had to flee."

"du jə mɪs jəɹ oʊld laɪf?"

"Do you miss your old life?"

ɛlaɪəs ʃɹʌɡd - pɛɹɪn kəd hɪɹ ðə moʊʃən, ðə kloʊðɪŋ skɹeɪpɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf. "noʊ wɔɹɾɝ wɑns tə əbændən ɪz duɾi. səmtaɪmz, ʌðɝ θɪŋz ɑɹ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. əɹ . . . wɛl, meɪbi ðeɪ ɑɹ dʒʌs mɔɹ dɪmændɪŋ. aɪ doʊn ɹəɡɹɛt maɪ tʃɔɪsəz."

Elyas shrugged - Perrin could hear the motion, the clothing scraping against itself. "No Warder wants to abandon his duty. Sometimes, other things are more important. Or . . . well, maybe they are just more demanding. I don't regret my choices."

"aɪ kæn liv, ɛlaɪəs. aɪ woʊnt"

"I can't leave, Elyas. I won't"

"aɪ lɛf maɪ laɪf fəɹ ðə wʊlvz. ðət dʌzn min juv tə."

"I left my life for the wolves. That doesn't mean you have to."

"noʊm hæd tə," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Noam had to," Perrin said.

"dɪɾ i hæv tə?" ɛlaɪəs sɛd.

"Did he have to?" Elyas said.

"ɪt kənsum hɪm. hi stɑp biɪŋ hjumən."

"It consumed him. He stopped being human."

hi kɑɾ ə sɛn ʌv wɝi. ɛlaɪəs hæd noʊ ænsɝz.

He caught a scent of worry. Elyas had no answers.

"du jə ɛvɝ vɪzət wʊlvz ɪn jəɹ dʒɹimz, ɛlaɪəs?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "ə pleɪs wɛɹ dɛd wʊlvz ɹʌn ən lɪv əɡɛn?"

"Do you ever visit wolves in your dreams, Elyas?" Perrin asked. "A place where dead wolves run and live again?"

ɛlaɪəs tɝnd, aɪɪŋ hɪm. "ðæt pleɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs, pɛɹɪn. ɪts ənʌðɝ wɝld, ɔlðoʊ taɪd tə ðɪs wʌn sʌmhaʊ. lɛdʒənz seɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv oʊl kəd ɡoʊ ðɛɹ."

Elyas turned, eyeing him. "That place is dangerous, Perrin. It's another world, although tied to this one somehow. Legends say the Aes Sedai of old could go there."

ən ʌðɝ pipəl, tu," pɛɹɪn sɛd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə sleɪɝ.

And other people, too," Perrin said, thinking of Slayer.

bi kɛɹfəl ɪn ðə dʒɹim. aɪ steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɪt." hɪz sɛnt wɑz wɛɹi.

Be careful in the dream. I stay away from it." His scent was wary.

dʒju ɛvɝ əv tʃɹʌbəl?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf fɹəm ðə wʊlf?"

Do you ever have trouble?" Perrin asked. "Separating yourself from the wolf?"

"aɪ juz tə."

"I used to."

"bʌt nɑɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ?"

"But not any longer?"

"aɪ faʊn ə bæləns," ɛlaɪəs sɛd.

"I found a balance," Elyas said.

"haʊ?"

"How?"

ði oʊldɝ mæn fɛl stɪl fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst sʌm-θɪŋ aɪ lɝnd, pɛɹɪn.

The older man fell still for a moment. "I wish I knew. It was just some-thing I learned, Perrin.

sʌmθɪŋ jəl əv tə lɝn."

Something you'll have to learn."

əɹ ɛn ʌp laɪk noʊm. pɛɹɪn mɛɾ ɛlaɪəs' ɡoʊldən aɪz, ðən nɑɾəd "θæŋk ju."

Or end up like Noam. Perrin met Elyas' golden eyes, then nodded "Thank you."

"fɔɹ ði ædvaɪs?"

"For the advice?"

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "fɔɹ kʌmɪŋ bæk. fəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ mi ðət wʌn ʌv əs ət list, kən lɪv wɪð ðə wʊlvz ən nɑt luz hɪmsɛlf."

"No," Perrin said. "For coming back. For showing me that one of us at least, can live with the wolves and not lose himself."

"ɪts nʌθɪŋ," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "aɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðəɾ ɪt kəd bi naɪs tə bi ɝaʊn pipəl fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ lɔŋ aɪ kən steɪ, ðoʊ. ðə læs hʌn ɪz ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ."

"It's nothing," Elyas said. "I had forgotten that it could be nice to be around people for a change. I don't know how long I can stay, though. The Last Hunt is almost here."

pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ðə skaɪ əɡɛn. "ðæɾ ɪɾ ɪz. pæs ðə wɝɾ ɑn tə tæm ən ði ʌðɝz fəɹ mi. aɪv meɪd maɪ dɪsɪʒən. ðə waɪtkloʊks əv pɪkt ə pleɪs tə faɪt. aɪv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən miɾ əm təmɑɹoʊ."

Perrin looked up at the sky again. "That it is. Pass the word on to Tam and the others for me. I've made my decision. The Whitecloaks have picked a place to fight. I've decided to go ahead and meet them tomorrow."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "ju doʊn smɛl laɪk jə wɑnə də ɪt, ðoʊ."

"All right," Elyas said. "You don't smell like you want to do it, though."

"ɪt nidz tə bi dʌn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn ðæts ðæt." ɛvɹiwʌn wɑntəɾ ɪm tə bi ə lɔɹd. wɛl, ðɪs wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ lɔɹdz dɪd. meɪd dɪsɪʒənz ðət noʊbɑdi wɑntəd tə meɪk.

"It needs to be done," Perrin said. "And that's that." Everyone wanted him to be a lord. Well, this was the sort of thing lords did. Made decisions that nobody wanted to make.

ɪt wəd stɪl sɪkən ɪm tə ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ. hid sin ə vɪʒən ə ðoʊz wʊlvz ɹʌnɪŋ ʃip təwɔɹɾ ə bist. ɪt sim tə hɪm ðət meɪbi ðət wɑz wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, ɹʌnɪŋ ðə waɪtkloʊks təwɔɹd dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. ðeɪ sɝɾənli wɔɹ ðə kʌlɝ ə ʃips wʊl.

It would still sicken him to give the order. He'd seen a vision of those wolves running sheep toward a beast. It seemed to him that maybe that was what he was doing, running the Whitecloaks toward destruction. They certainly wore the color of sheep's wool.

bʌt wʌt tə meɪk ə ðə vɪʒən ə feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ə klɪf? ɛlaɪəs muvd ɔf, livɪŋ pɛɹɪn wɪð ði æks stɪl ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i hædn bɪn tʃɑpɪŋ lɔɡz, bʌt bɑɾiz.

But what to make of the vision of Faile and the others, approaching a cliff? Elyas moved off, leaving Perrin with the axe still on his shoulder. He felt as if he hadn't been chopping logs, but bodies.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv


CHAPTER 25

ɹɪtɝn tə bændɑɹ ɛbən


Return to Bandar Eban

ɹænd ən mɪn dɪd nɑɾ ənaʊns ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðeɪ keɪm tə bændɑɹ ɛbən. ðeɪ stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪndə ə smɔl æli, ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ tu meɪɾənz - lɹiən ən haɪɾiə - əlɔŋ wɪð nf, ðə tɔl, skwɛɹ-tʃɪn æʃəmən.

Rand and Min did not announce themselves as they came to Bandar Eban. They stepped through the gateway into a small alley, guarded by two Maidens - Lerian and Heidia - along with Naeff, the tall, square-chinned Asha'man.

ðə meɪɾənz skaʊɾəd tə ði ɛn ə ði æliweɪ, piɹɪŋ səspɪʃəsli ət ðə sɪɾi. ɹænd stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn haɪɾiəz ʃoʊldɝ, kɑmɪŋ ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən, hu simd æŋkʃəs ət ɹændz ɡɑɹd biɪŋ soʊ fju. hi wɔɹ ɪz bɹaʊn kloʊk.

The Maidens scouted to the end of the alleyway, peering suspiciously at the city. Rand stepped forward and laid a hand on Heidias shoulder, calming the slender woman, who seemed anxious at Rand's guard being so few. He wore his brown cloak.

oʊvɝhɛd, ðə klaʊdz bɹoʊk, mɛltɪŋ əweɪ əbʌv ðə sɪɾi ɪn ɹɪspɑns tə ɹændz ɝaɪvəl. mɪn lʊkt ʌpwɝd, filɪŋ ðə wɔɹmθ ʃaɪn ɑn əɹ feɪs. ði æli smɛl tɛɹəbəl - ʌv ɹɛfjus ən weɪst  - bʌɾ ə wɔɹm bɹiz blu θɹu, kæɹiɪŋ ðə stɛntʃɪz əweɪ.

Overhead, the clouds broke, melting away above the city in response to Rand's arrival. Min looked upward, feeling the warmth shine on her face. The alley smelled terrible - of refuse and waste  - but a warm breeze blew through, carrying the stenches away.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," nf sɛd. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs. jə ʃəɾ əv ɡtiɾɝ pɹətɛkʃən. lɛɾ əs ɹɪtɝn ən ɡæðɝ - "

"My Lord Dragon," Naeff said. "I don't like this. You should have gteater protection. Let us return and gather - "

"ɪt wɪl bi faɪn, nf," ɹænd sɛd. hi tɝn tə mɪn ən hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hænd.

"It will be fine, Naeff," Rand said. He turned to Min and held out his hand.

ʃi tʊk ɪt, dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɪm. nf ən ðə meɪɾənz hæɾ ɔɹɾɝz tə fɑloʊ bɪhaɪn əɾ ə dɪstəns; ðeɪ wəd dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən.

She took it, joining him. Naeff and the Maidens had orders to follow behind at a distance; they would draw attention.

əz mɪn ən ɹænd stɛpt aʊɾ ɑntu wʌn ə ðə dəmɑni kæpəɾəlz mɛni bɔɹdwɔks, ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ maʊð. ɪt hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ə ʃɔɹt taɪm sɪns ɹændz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. haʊ hæd ðə sɪɾi tʃeɪnʒd soʊ kwɪkli?

As Min and Rand stepped out onto one of the Domani capital's many boardwalks, she raised a hand to her mouth. It had only been a short time since Rand's departure. How had the city changed so quickly?

ðə stʃɹit wɑz fʊl ə sɪkli, dɝɾi pipəl, kɹaʊɾəd əlɔŋsaɪd wɔlz, hʌɾəld ɪn blæŋkəts. ðəɹ wɑzn ɹum tə muv ɑn ðə bɔɹdwɔks; mɪn ən ɹænd hæd tə stɛp daʊn ɪndə ðə mʌd tə kəntɪnju.

The street was full of sickly, dirty people, crowded alongside walls, huddled in blankets. There wasn't room to move on the boardwalks; Min and Rand had to step down into the mud to continue.

pipəl kɔft ən moʊnd, ən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðə stɛntʃɪz wɝn kənfaɪn tə ði æli. ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi sim tə stɪŋk. wʌns, bænɝz hæd hʌŋ fɹəm mɛni ʌv ðiz bɪldɪŋz, bʌt ðeɪd bɪn pʊl daʊn ən ɹɪpt əpɑɹt fəɹ blæŋkəts əɹ fjuəl.

People coughed and moaned, and she realized the stenches weren't confined to the alley. The entire city seemed to stink. Once, banners had hung from many of these buildings, but they'd been pulled down and ripped apart for blankets or fuel.

moʊst ə ðə bɪldɪŋz hæd bɹoʊkən wɪndoʊz, wɪð ɹɛfjudʒiz klɑɡɪŋ ðə dɔɹweɪz ən flɔɹz ɪnsaɪd. əz mɪn ən ɹænd wɔkt, ðə pipəl ɝaʊn əm tɝn tə wɑtʃ. səm lʊk dɪlɪɹiəs.

Most of the buildings had broken windows, with refugees clogging the doorways and floors inside. As Min and Rand walked, the people around them turned to watch. Some looked delirious.

ʌðɝz lʊk hʌŋɡɹi. ən deɪnʒɝəs. mɛni wɝ dəmɑni, bʌt ðəɹ sim tə bi əz mɛni pəlɝ- skɪn pipəl. ɹɛfjudʒiz fɹəm ɑlməθ pleɪn əɹ sɑldɑiə, pɝhæps. mɪn lusən ə naɪf ɪn əɹ sliv əz ðeɪ pæst ə ɡɹup ə jʌŋ tʌfs laʊnʒɪŋ əɾ ən æli weɪ ɛs maʊθ. pɝhæps nf hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. ðɪs dɪdn fil seɪf.

Others looked hungry. And dangerous. Many were Domani, but there seemed to be as many paler- skinned people. Refugees from Almoth Plain or Saldaea, perhaps. Min loosened a knife in her sleeve as they passed a group of young toughs lounging at an alley way s mouth. Perhaps Naeff had been right. This didn't feel safe.

"aɪ wɔk θɹu ɛbu dɑɹ laɪk ðɪs," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. sʌɾənli, ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɪz peɪn. ə kɹʌʃɪŋ ɡɪlt, mɔɹ hɝtfəl ðən ðə wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd. "ðæt wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt meɪd mi tʃeɪnʒ. ðə pipəl ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ wɝ hæpi ən wɛl-fɛd. ðeɪ dɪdn lʊk laɪk ðiz. ðə sintʃæn ɹul bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ."

"I walked through Ebou Dar like this," Rand said softly. Suddenly, she was aware of his pain. A crushing guilt, more hurtful than the wounds in his side. "That was part of what made me change. The people in Ebou Dar were happy and well-fed. They didn't look like these. The Seanchan rule better than I."

"ɹænd, jə ɑɹən ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðɪs," mɪn sɛd. "ju wɝn hɪɹ tə . . ."

"Rand, you aren't responsible for this," Min said. "You weren't here to . . ."

hɪz peɪn ɪnkɹist, ən ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃid sɛd ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ. "jɛs," hi ɹɪplaɪd sɔfli, "aɪ wɑzn hɪɹ. aɪ əbændən ðɪs sɪɾi wən aɪ sɔ ðəɾ aɪ kəd nɑt juz ɪɾ əz ðə tul aɪ wɪʃt ɪt tə bi. aɪ fɝɡɑt, mɪn. aɪ fɝɡɑt wʌt ðɪs wɑz ɔl əbaʊt. tɑɹn wɑz soʊ vɛɹi ɹaɪt. ə mæn mʌs noʊ waɪ hiz faɪɾɪŋ."

His pain increased, and she realized she'd said the wrong thing. "Yes," he replied softly, "I wasn't here. I abandoned this city when I saw that I could not use it as the tool I wished it to be. I forgot, Min. I forgot what this was all about. Tarn was so very right. A man must know why he is fighting."

ɹænd hæd sɛn ɪz fɑðɝ - əlɔŋ wɪð wʌn ə ði æʃəmən - tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz tə pɹipɛɹ ən ɡæðɝ əm fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

Rand had sent his father - along with one of the Ashaman - to the Two Rivers to prepare and gather them for the Last Battle.

ɹænd stʌmbəld əz i wɔkt, sʌɾənli lʊkɪŋ vɛɹi taɪɝd. hi sæt daʊn ɑn ə nɪɹbaɪ bɑks. ə kɑpɝ-skɪn ɝtʃən wɑtʃt ɪm kinli fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ dɔɹweɪ. əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, ə ɹoʊdweɪ bɹæntʃt ɔf ðə meɪn θɝoʊfɛɹ. ðət wʌn wɑzn klɔɡd wɪð pipəl; bɹuɾɪʃ-lʊkɪŋ mɛn wɪð kʌdʒəlz stʊɾ əɾ ɪts maʊθ.

Rand stumbled as he walked, suddenly looking very tired. He sat down on a nearby box. A copper-skinned urchin watched him keenly from a nearby doorway. Across the street, a roadway branched off the main thoroughfare. That one wasn't clogged with people; brutish-looking men with cudgels stood at its mouth.

"ðeɪ bɹeɪk ɪndə ɡæŋz," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, ʃoʊldɝz boʊɪŋ. "ðə ɹɪtʃ haɪɝ ðə stʃɹɔŋ tə pɹətɛk ðɛm, tə faɪɾ əweɪ ðoʊz u kʌm sikɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛlθ. bʌɾ ɪts nɑɾ ə wɛlθ ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ dʒuəlɹi. ɪts əbaʊt fud, naʊ."

"They break into gangs," Rand said softly, shoulders bowing. "The rich hire the strong to protect them, to fight away those who come seeking their wealth. But it's not a wealth of gold or jewelry. It's about food, now."

"ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, ɡoʊɪŋ tə wʌn ni bɪsaɪd hɪm. "ju kænt - "

"Rand," she said, going to one knee beside him. "You can't - "

"aɪ noʊ aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ ɑn," ɹænd sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪt hɝts tə noʊ ðə θɪŋz ðəɾ aɪv dʌn, mɪn. baɪ tɝnɪŋ maɪsɛlf tə stil, aɪ pʊʃt aʊɾ ɔl ə ðiz ɪmoʊʃənz. baɪ əlaʊɪŋ maɪsɛlf tə kɛɹ əɡɛn, tə læf əɡɛn, aɪv hæd tə oʊpən maɪsɛlf tə maɪ feɪljɝz, tu."

"I know I must go on," Rand said, "but it hurts to know the things that I've done, Min. By turning myself to steel, I pushed out all of these emotions. By allowing myself to care again, to laugh again, I've had to open myself to my failures, too."

"ɹænd, aɪ si sʌnlaɪɾ ɝaʊn ju."

"Rand, I see sunlight around you."

hi lʊkt ʌp ət hɝ, ðən ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ.

He looked up at her, then glanced at the sky.

"nɑt ðət sʌnlaɪt," mɪn wɪspɝd. "ə vjuɪŋ. aɪ si dɑɹk klaʊdz, pʊʃt əweɪ baɪ ðə sʌnlaɪts wɔɹmθ. aɪ si ju, ə bɹɪljənt waɪt sɔɹd hɛld ɪn jəɹ hænd, wildɪɾ əɡɛnst wʌn ə blæk, hɛl baɪ ə feɪsləs dɑɹknəs. aɪ si tʃɹiz, ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɡɹin əɡɛn, bɛɹɪŋ fɹut. aɪ si ə fild, ðə kɹɑps hɛlθi ən fʊl." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ si ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɹænd. aɪ si ən ɪn ðəɹ wɪð ðə mɑɹk ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ ɪnleɪɾ ɑn ɪts dɔɹ. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi ə sɪmbəl ə dɑɹknəs əɹ heɪt. ə saɪn ə vɪktɝi ən hoʊp."

"Not that sunlight," Min whispered. "A viewing. I see dark clouds, pushed away by the sunlight's warmth. I see you, a brilliant white sword held in your hand, wielded against one of black, held by a faceless darkness. I see trees, growing green again, bearing fruit. I see a field, the crops healthy and full." She hesitated. "I see the Two Rivers, Rand. I see an inn there with the mark of the Dragon's Fang inlaid on its door. No longer be a symbol of darkness or hate. A sign of victory and hope."

hi lʊk tə hɝ.

He looked to her.

mɪn kɑt sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. ʃi tɝn təwɔɹd ðə pipəl sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə stʃɹit, ən ɡeɪpt. ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl wʌn hæɾ ən ɪmədʒ əbʌv ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl tə si soʊ mɛni vjuɪŋz, ɔl ət wʌns, flɛɹɪŋ tə laɪɾ əbʌv ðə hɛdz ə ðə sɪkli, ðə wik, ən ði əbændənd.

Min caught something from the corner of her eye. She turned toward the people sitting on the street, and gaped. Every single one had an image above them. It was remarkable to see so many viewings, all at once, flaring to light above the heads of the sickly, the weak, and the abandoned.

"aɪ si ə sɪlvɝ æks əbʌv ðət mænz hɛd," ʃi sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə bɪɹɾəd bɛɡɝ, hu leɪ əɡɛnst ə wɔl, hɪz tʃɪn daʊn əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. "hi wɪl bi ə liɾɝ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl. ðət wʊmən ðəɹ -  ðə wʌn sʌlkɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz - ʃɪl bi tʃɹeɪn baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ kən si ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪsaɪd hɝ, ən aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz. ðət mæn oʊvɝ ðəɹ u lʊks laɪk ə sɪmpəl stʃɹit tʌf? hɪl seɪv əɹ laɪf. aɪ noʊ hi dʌzn lʊk laɪk ɪt, bʌt hɪl faɪt. ɔl ə ðɛm wɪl. aɪ kən si ɪt!"

"I see a silver axe above that man's head," she said, pointing to a bearded beggar, who lay against a wall, his chin down against his chest. "He will be a leader in the Last Battle. That woman there -  the one sulking in the shadows - she will be trained by the White Tower and become Aes Sedai. I can see the Flame of Tar Valon beside her, and I know what it means. That man over there who looks like a simple street tough? He will save her life. I know he doesn't look like it, but he will fight. All of them will. I can see it!"

ʃi lʊkt ət ɹænd ən tʊk ɪz hænd. "ju wɪl bi stʃɹɔŋ, ɹænd. jəl də ðɪs. jəl lɛd ðɛm. aɪ noʊ ɪt."

She looked at Rand and took his hand. "You will be strong, Rand. You'll do this. You'll lead them. I know it."

"ju sɔ ðæt?" hi æskt. "ɪn ə vjuɪŋ?"

"You saw that?" he asked. "In a viewing?"

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ doʊnt nid tə. aɪ bɪliv ɪn ju." aɪ ɔlmoʊs kɪl ju," hi wɪspɝd. "wɛn jə lʊk ət mi, jə si ə mɝɾɝɝ. jə fil maɪ hæn ət jəɹ θɹoʊt."

She shook her head. "I don't need to. I believe in you." I almost killed you," he whispered. "When you look at me, you see a murderer. You feel my hand at your throat."

"wʌt? ʌv kɔɹs aɪ doʊnt! ɹænd, mit maɪ aɪz. jə kən sɛns mi θɹu ðə bɑnd. dʒju fil ə slɪvɝ ə hɛzəteɪʃən əɹ fɪɹ fɹəm mi?"

"What? Of course I don't! Rand, meet my eyes. You can sense me through the bond. Do you feel a sliver of hesitation or fear from me?"

hi sɝtʃt əɹ aɪz wɪð ɪz oʊn, soʊ dip. ʃi dɪdn bæk daʊn. ʃi kəd mit ði aɪz ə ðɪs ʃifɝɾɝ.

He searched her eyes with his own, so deep. She didn't back down. She could meet the eyes of this sheepherder.

hi sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ. "oʊ, mɪn. wʌt wəɾ aɪ də wɪθaʊt ju?"

He sat up straighter. "Oh, Min. What would I do without you?"

ʃi snɔɹɾɪd. "ju hæv kɪŋz ən il tʃifs fɑloʊɪŋ ju. ɛɛs sədaɪ, æʃəmən, ən tɑvɝən.

She snorted. "You have kings and Aiel chiefs following you. Aes Sedai, Asha'man, and ta'veren.

aɪm sɝɾən jud ɡɛɾ əlɔŋ."

I'm certain you'd get along."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "jɔɹ mɔɹ vaɪɾəl ðən əm ɔl. jə ɹimaɪn mi hu aɪ æm. bɪsaɪdz, jə θɪŋk mɔɹ klɪɹli ðən moʊst ə ðoʊz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz maɪ kaʊnsəlɝz.

"No," Rand said. "You're more vital than them all. You remind me who I am. Besides, you think more clearly than most of those who call themselves my counselors.

jə kəd bi ə kwin, ɪf jə wɪʃt ɪt."

You could be a queen, if you wished it."

"ɔl aɪ wɪʃ fəɹ ɪz ju, stupəd lubi."

"All I wish for is you, stupid looby."

"θæŋk ju." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ðoʊ aɪ kəd mænədʒ wɪθaʊt kwaɪt soʊ mʌtʃ neɪm kɔlɪŋ."

"Thank you." He hesitated. "Though I could manage without quite so much name calling."

"laɪfs tʌf, ɪzən ɪt?"

"Life's tough, isn't it?"

hi smaɪld. ðən i stʊd, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ. hɪz ɡɪlt wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, bʌɾ i mænədʒd ɪt naʊ, əz i mænədʒ ðə peɪn. nɪɹbaɪ, ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz pɝkt ʌp. ɹænd tɝn təwɔɹd ðə bɪɹɾəd ɹɛtʃ mɪn hæɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ɝliɝ; ðə mæn sæt wɪð ɪz fiɾ ɪn ðə mʌd.

He smiled. Then he stood, taking a deep breath. His guilt was still there, but he managed it now, as he managed the pain. Nearby, the refugees perked up. Rand turned toward the bearded wretch Min had indicated earlier; the man sat with his feet in the mud.

"ju," ðə mæn sɛd tə ɹænd, "jɔɹ hɪm. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"You," the man said to Rand, "you're him. The Dragon Reborn."

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd. "ju wɝ ə soʊlʒɝ?"

"Yes," Rand said. "You were a soldier?"

"aɪ. . ." ðə mænz aɪz ɡɹu dɪstənt. "ənʌðɝ laɪf. aɪ wɑz ɪn ðə kɪŋz ɡɑɹd, bɪfɔɹ i wɑz teɪkən, bɪfɔɹ wi wɝ siz baɪ leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ, ðən dɪsbændɪd." ðə fətiɡ sim tə blid fɹəm ɪz aɪz əz i θɔɾ ə ɝliɝ deɪz.

"I. . ." The man's eyes grew distant. "Another life. I was in the King's Guard, before he was taken, before we were seized by Lady Chadmar, then disbanded." The fatigue seemed to bleed from his eyes as he thought of earlier days.

"ɛksələnt," ɹænd sɛd. "wi nid tə ɹɪstɔɹ ðɪs sɪɾi, kæptən."

"Excellent," Rand said. "We need to restore this city, Captain."

"kæptən?" ðə mæn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ. . ." hi kɑkt ɪz hɛd. ðən i stʊɾ ʌp ən bɹʌʃt hɪmsɛlf ɔf. hi sʌɾənli hæɾ ə feɪnli mɪlətɛɹi ɛɹ əbaʊt hɪm, dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɪp kloʊðɪŋ ən ðə snɑɹəl bɪɹd. "wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ ɹaɪt. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɪɾəl bi izi. ðə pipəl ɑɹ stɑɹvɪŋ."

"Captain?" the man said. "But I. . ." He cocked his head. Then he stood up and brushed himself off. He suddenly had a faintly military air about him, despite the ripped clothing and the snarled beard. "Well, I suppose you're right. But I don't think it'll be easy. The people are starving."

"aɪ wɪl si tə ðæt," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ nid jə tə ɡæðɝ jəɹ soʊlʒɝz."

"I will see to that," Rand said. "I need you to gather your soldiers."

"aɪ doʊn si mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ lædz hɪɹ. . . . noʊ, weɪt. ðɛɹz voʊɾəbɛk ən ɹɛdbɔɹd." hi weɪv tə ə pɛɹ ə ðə tʌfs mɪn hæd noʊɾəst ɝliɝ. ðeɪ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən wɔkt oʊvɝ.

"I don't see many of the other lads here. . . . No, wait. There's Votabek and Redbord." He waved to a pair of the toughs Min had noticed earlier. They hesitated, then walked over.

"dɝnəm?" wʌn ə ðɛm æskt. "wʌts ðɪs?"

"Durnham?" one of them asked. "What's this?"

"ɪts taɪm fəɹ ðə lɔləsnəs ɪn ðə sɪɾi tə ɛnd," dɝnəm sɛd. "wɝ gɑnə ɔɹɡənaɪz θɪŋz, klin ɪɾ ʌp. ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən əz ɹɪtɝnd."

"It's time for the lawlessness in the city to end," Durnham said. "We're going to organize things, clean it up. The Lord Dragon has returned."

wʌn ə ðɛm spæt tə ðə saɪd. hi wɑz ə bɝli mæn wɪð kɝli blæk hɛɹ, dəmɑni skɪn, ən ə θɪn mʌstæʃ. "bɝn hɪm. hi lɛft ʌs. aɪ - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əz sɔ ɹænd.

One of them spat to the side. He was a burly man with curly black hair, Domani skin, and a thin mustache. "Burn him. He left us. I - " He cut off as saw Rand.

"aɪm sɑɹi," ɹænd sɛd, miɾɪŋ ðə mænz aɪz. "aɪ feɪl ju. əl nɑt də soʊ əɡɛn."

"I'm sorry," Rand said, meeting the man's eyes. "I failed you. I will not do so again."

ðə mæn ɡlænst əɾ ɪz kəmpænjən, hu ʃɹʌɡd. "leɪnz nɛvɝ gɑnə peɪ ʌs. maɪɾ əz wɛl si wʌt wi kən də hɪɹ."

The man glanced at his companion, who shrugged. "Lain's never going to pay us. Might as well see what we can do here."

"nf," ɹænd kɔld, weɪvɪŋ ði æʃəmən fɔɹwɝd. hi ən ðə meɪɾənz stɛpt ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ. "meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ bæk tə ðə stoʊn. aɪ wɑnt wɛpənz, ɑɹmɝ ən junəfɔɹmz."

"Naeff," Rand called, waving the Asha'man forward. He and the Maidens stepped up from where they had been watching. "Make a gateway back to the Stone. I want weapons, armor and uniforms."

"aɪl də ɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli," nf sɛd. "wil əv soʊlʒɝz bɹɪŋ əm -  "noʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "pæs ðə səplaɪz θɹu, ɪndə ðɪs bɪldɪŋ hɪɹ.

"I'll do it immediately," Naeff said. "We'll have soldiers bring them -  "No," Rand said. "Pass the supplies through, into this building here.

əl klɪɹ ə pleɪs fəɹ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt. bʌt noʊ soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ tə kʌm."

I'll clear a place for the gateway inside it. But no soldiers are to come."

ɹænd ɹeɪzd ɪz aɪz, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə stʃɹit. "bændɑɹ ɛbən əz sʌfɝɾ ɪnʌf bɪniθ ðə hænz ʌv aʊtsaɪɾɝz. tədeɪ, ʃɪl nɑt noʊ ðə hæn ʌv ə kɑŋkɝɝ."

Rand raised his eyes, looking at the street. "Bandar Eban has suffered enough beneath the hands of outsiders. Today, she will not know the hand of a conqueror."

mɪn stɛp bæk, ən wɑtʃt wɪð wʌndɝ. ðə θɹi soʊlʒɝz hæz-tɛn ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ ən klɪɹɾ aʊt ði ɝtʃənz. wən ɹænd sɔ ðɛm i æskt əm tə bi mɛsənʒɝz tə ɹʌn ɛɹənz. ðeɪ ɹɪspɑndɪd. ɛvɹiwʌn ɹɪspɑndɪd tə ɹænd, wən ðeɪ tʊk taɪm tə lʊk ət hɪm.

Min stepped back, and watched with wonder. The three soldiers has-tened into the building and cleared out the urchins. When Rand saw them he asked them to be messengers to run errands. They responded. Everyone responded to Rand, when they took time to look at him.

pɝhæps ənʌðɝ maɪɾ əv θɔɾ ɪt səm fɔɹm ə kəmpʌlʃən, bʌt mɪn sɔ ðɛɹ feɪsəz tʃeɪnʒ, sɔ hoʊp ɹɪtɝn əz ə ɡlɪmɝ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ðeɪ sɔ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd ðeɪ kəd tʃɹʌst.

Perhaps another might have thought it some form of Compulsion, but Min saw their faces change, saw hope return as a glimmer in their eyes. They saw something about Rand they could trust.

sʌmθɪŋ, ət list, ðeɪ hoʊp ðeɪ kəd tʃɹʌst.

Something, at least, they hoped they could trust.

ðə θɹi soʊlʒɝz sɛn ə fju ʌv ðə mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪz ən ɡɝlz tə fɛtʃ ʌðɝ fɔɹmɝ soʊlʒɝz. nf meɪɾ ɪz ɡeɪtweɪ. ɪn mɪnəts, ði ɝɪdʒənəl θɹi soʊlʒɝz stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ, wɛɹɪŋ sɪlvɝi bɹɛstpleɪts ən sɪmpəl, klin kloʊðɪŋ ʌv ɡɹin. ðə mɛn hæd koʊm ðɛɹ bɪɹdz ən hɛɹ ən faʊn səm wɔɾɝ tə wɑʃ ðɛɹ feɪsəz əz kwɪkli əz ðæt, ðeɪ stɑp lʊkɪŋ laɪk bɛɡɝz ən bɪkeɪm soʊlʒɝz. ə bɪt smɛli, bʌt soʊlʒɝz nʌnðəlɛs.

The three soldiers sent a few of the messenger boys and girls to fetch other former soldiers. Naeff made his gateway. In minutes, the original three soldiers stepped out of the building, wearing silvery breastplates and simple, clean clothing of green. The men had combed their beards and hair and found some water to wash their faces As quickly as that, they stopped looking like beggars and became soldiers. A bit smelly, but soldiers nonetheless.

ðə wʊmən mɪn hæd noʊɾəd ɝliɝ - ðə wʌn ʃi wɑz sɝɾən kəd lɝn tə tʃænəl - keɪm oʊvɝ tə spik wɪð ɹænd. æftɝ ə bɪt, ʃi nɑɾəd, ən sun hæd ɡæðɝd wɪmən ən mɛn tə fɪl bʌkəts fɹəm ðə wɛl. mɪn fɹaʊn ət ðəɾ əntɪl ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd waɪpɪŋ klin ðə feɪsəz ən hænz ə ðoʊz u əpɹoʊtʃt.

The woman Min had noted earlier - the one she was certain could learn to channel - came over to speak with Rand. After a bit, she nodded, and soon had gathered women and men to fill buckets from the well. Min frowned at that until they started wiping clean the faces and hands of those who approached.

pipəl bɪɡæn tə ɡæðɝ ɝaʊnd. səm kjʊɹiəs, ʌðɝz hɑstəl, stɪl ʌðɝz mɪɹli kɑɾ ɪn ðə floʊ. ðə wʊmən ən əɹ tim bɪɡæn sɔɹɾɪŋ θɹu ðɛm ən sɛɾɪŋ əm tə wɝk. səm tə sik aʊt ðə wundəɾ əɹ sɪkli, ʌðɝz tə teɪk ʌp sɔɹdz ən junəfɔɹmz. ənʌðɝ wʊmən bɪɡæn ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪŋ ði ɝtʃənz, dɪskʌvɝɪŋ wɛɹ ðɛɹ pɛɹəns wɝ, ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɛni.

People began to gather around. Some curious, others hostile, still others merely caught in the flow. The woman and her team began sorting through them and setting them to work. Some to seek out the wounded or sickly, others to take up swords and uniforms. Another woman began interrogating the urchins, discovering where their parents were, if they had any.

mɪn sæt daʊn ɑn ðə bɑks ðət ɹænd hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɑn. wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ, hi hæɾ ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz faɪv hʌnʒɹəd stʃɹɔŋ, lɛd baɪ kæptən dɝn-hæm ən ɪz tu lutɛnəns. mɛni ʌv ðoʊz faɪv hʌnʒɹəd kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn ət ðɛɹ klin kloʊðɪŋ ən sɪlvɝi bɹɛstpleɪts əz ɪf əmeɪzd.

Min sat down on the box that Rand had been sitting on. Within the hour, he had a group of soldiers five hundred strong, led by Captain Durn-ham and his two lieutenants. Many of those five hundred kept glancing down at their clean clothing and silvery breastplates as if amazed.

ɹænd spoʊk wɪð mɛni ʌv ðɛm, əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ dɝɛkli. əz i wɑz spik-ɪŋ tə wʌn wʊmən, ðə kɹaʊd bɪhaɪn bɪɡæn tə ʃʌfəl ən muv. ɹænd tɝn tə si ən eɪdʒɪd mæn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, hɪz skɪn bɹoʊkən baɪ tɛɹəbəl liʒənz. ðə kɹaʊd kɛpt ɪts dɪstəns.

Rand spoke with many of them, apologizing directly. As he was speak-ing to one woman, the crowd behind began to shuffle and move. Rand turned to see an aged man approaching, his skin broken by terrible lesions. The crowd kept its distance.

"nf," ɹænd kɔld.

"Naeff," Rand called.

"maɪ lɔɹd?"

"My Lord?"

"bɹɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ θɹu," ɹænd sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ pipəl u ɹeɪ-kwaɪɹ hilɪŋ." ðə wʊmən u hæd ɡɑɾən pipəl tə fɪl wɔɾɝ bʌkəts lɛd ði oʊl mæn tə wʌn saɪd.

"Bring the Aes Sedai through," Rand said. "There are people who re-quire Healing." The woman who had gotten people to fill water buckets led the old man to one side.

"maɪ lɔɹd," kæptən dɝnəm sɛd, mɑɹtʃɪŋ ʌp. mɪn blɪŋkt. ðə mæn hæd faʊn ə ɹeɪzɝ sʌmwɛɹ ən ʃeɪvd ɔf ɪz bɪɹd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə stʃɹɔŋ tʃɪn. hid lɛft ə dəmɑni mʌstæʃ. fɔɹ mɛn fɑloʊɾ ɪm əz ə ɡɑɹd.

"My Lord," Captain Durnham said, marching up. Min blinked. The man had found a razor somewhere and shaved off his beard, revealing a strong chin. He'd left a Domani mustache. Four men followed him as a guard.

"wɝ gɑnə nid mɔɹ ɹum, maɪ lɔɹd," dɝnəm sɛd. "ðæt bɪldɪŋ jə tʃoʊz ɪz oʊvɝfloʊɪŋ, ən mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ, fɪlɪŋ ðə stʃɹit."

"We're going to need more room, my Lord," Durnham said. "That building you chose is overflowing, and more and more are coming, filling the street."

"wʌt dʒju sədʒɛst?" ɹænd æskt.

"What do you suggest?" Rand asked.

"ðə dɑks," dɝnəm ɹɪplaɪd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ hɛl baɪ wʌn ə ðə sɪɾi mɝtʃəns. əl weɪdʒɝ wi kən faɪn səm nɪɹ-ɛmpti wɛɹhaʊzɪz tə juz. ðoʊz wʌns hɛl fud bʌt . . . wɛl, ðəɹ ɪzən ɛni lɛft."

"The docks," Durnham replied. "They are held by one of the city merchants. I'll wager we can find some near-empty warehouses to use. Those once held food but . . . well, there isn't any left."

"æn ðə mɝtʃən u hoʊlz ðə pleɪs?" ɹænd æskt.

"And the merchant who holds the place?" Rand asked.

"maɪ lɔɹd," kæptən dɝnəm sɛd, "nʌθɪŋ jə kæn dil wɪð."

"My Lord," Captain Durnham said, "nothing you can't deal with."

ɹænd smaɪld, ðən weɪv fəɹ dɝnəm tə lid ðə weɪ. ɹænd hɛld ɪz hæn aʊt tə mɪn.

Rand smiled, then waved for Durnham to lead the way. Rand held his hand out to Min.

"ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɪm, "ðeɪl nid fud."

"Rand," she said, joining him, "they'll need food."

"jɛs," hi əɡɹid. hi lʊk saʊθwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə nɪɹbaɪ dɑks. "wil faɪn ɪt ðɛɹ."

"Yes," he agreed. He looked southward, toward the nearby docks. "We'll find it there."

"woʊn ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv bɪn iɾən?"

"Won't it already have been eaten?"

ɹænd dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ. ðeɪ dʒɔɪn ðə nuli fɔɹm sɪɾi ɡɑɹd, wɔkɪŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə fɔɹs ɪn ɡɹin ən sɪlvɝ. bɪhaɪn əm tʃɹeɪld ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ θɹɔŋ ə hoʊpfəl ɹɛfjudʒiz.

Rand didn't reply. They joined the newly formed city guard, walking at the head of a force in green and silver. Behind them trailed a growing throng of hopeful refugees.

ði ɪnɔɹməs dɑks ə bændɑɹ ɛbən wɝ səm ə ðə moʊst ɪmpɹɛsɪv ɪn ðə wɝld. ðeɪ leɪ ɪn ə hæf-mun ət ðə beɪs ə ðə sɪɾi. mɪn wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si haʊ mɛni ʃɪps wɝ ðɛɹ, moʊst ə ðɛm si foʊk vɛsəlz.

The enormous docks of Bandar Eban were some of the most impressive in the world. They lay in a half-moon at the base of the city. Min was surprised to see how many ships were there, most of them Sea Folk vessels.

ðæts ɹaɪt, mɪn θɔt. ɹænd hæɾ əm bɹɪŋ fud tə ðə sɪɾi. bʌɾ ɪt hæd spɔɪld. əz ɹænd hæd lɛf ðə sɪɾi, hid ɡɑɾən wɝd ðəɾ ɔl ə ðə fuɾ ɑn ðoʊz ʃɪps hæd fɔlən tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ.

That's right, Min thought. Rand had them bring food to the city. But it had spoiled. As Rand had left the city, he'd gotten word that all of the food on those ships had fallen to the Dark One's touch.

sʌmwʌn hæd sɛɾ ʌp blɑkeɪdz ət ðə beɪs ə ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ʌðɝ ɹoʊdz tə ðə dɑks lʊk sɪməlɝli ɪnhɪbəɾɪd. junəfɔɹm soʊlʒɝz pikt aʊt nɝvəsli fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə bæɹəkeɪɾ əz ɹændz fɔɹs wɔkt ʌp.

Someone had set up blockades at the base of the roadway. Other roads to the docks looked similarly inhibited. Uniformed soldiers peeked out nervously from behind the barricade as Rand's force walked up.

"stɑp ɹaɪt ðɛɹ!" ə vɔɪs kɔld. "wi doʊnt - "

"Stop right there!" a voice called. "We don't - "

ɹænd lɪftəɾ ɪz hænd, ðən weɪvd ɪt kæʒəwəli. ðə bæɹəkeɪd - fɔɹmd ə fɝnɪtʃɝ ən plæŋks -  ɹʌmbəld, ðən slɪd tə ðə saɪd wɪð ə ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ʌv wʊd. mɛn kɹaɪɾ aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, skɹæmbəlɪŋ əweɪ.

Rand lifted his hand, then waved it casually. The barricade - formed of furniture and planks -  rumbled, then slid to the side with a grinding of wood. Men cried out from behind, scrambling away.

ɹænd lɛf ðə bæɹəkeɪd slʌmpt ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd. hi stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ən mɪn kəd sɛns pis ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. ə ɹæɡəd-lʊkɪŋ ɡɹup ə mɛn wɪð kʌdʒəlz stʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹoʊd, aɪz waɪd. ɹænd pɪkt wʌn ət ðə fɹʌnt. "hu ɪz ɪt ðət blɑks maɪ pipəl fɹəm ðiz dɑks ən siks tə hɔɹd fud fəɹ hɪmsɛlf? aɪ wəd . . . spik wɪð ðɪs pɝsən."

Rand left the barricade slumped at the side of the road. He stepped forward, and Min could sense peace inside of him. A ragged-looking group of men with cudgels stood in the road, eyes wide. Rand picked one at the front. "Who is it that blocks my people from these docks and seeks to hoard food for himself? I would . . . speak with this person."

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?" ə sɝpɹaɪz vɔɪs æskt.

"My Lord Dragon?" a surprised voice asked.

mɪn ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd. ə tɔl, lin mæn ɪn ə ɹɛd dəmɑni koʊt hʌsəl təwɔɹɾ əm fɹəm ðə dɑks. hɪz ʃɝt hæd wʌns bɪn faɪn ən ɹʌfəld, bʌt wɑz naʊ ɹɪŋkəld ən ənkɛmpt. hi lʊkt ɪɡzɔstəd.

Min glanced to the side. A tall, lean man in a red Domani coat hustled toward them from the docks. His shirt had once been fine and ruffled, but was now wrinkled and unkempt. He looked exhausted.

wʌt wɑz ɪz neɪm? mɪn θɔt. aɪɹlɪn. ðæts ɪt. mæstɝ ə ðə dɑks.

What was his name? Min thought. Iralin. That's it. Master of the docks.

"aɪɹlɪn?" ɹænd æskt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn hɪɹ? wʌɾ əv jə dʌn?"

"Iralin?" Rand asked. "What is going on here? What have you done?"

"wʌɾ əv / dʌn?" ðə mæn dɪmændəd. "aɪv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm ɹʌʃɪŋ ðoʊz ʃɪps fəɹ ðə spɔɪl fud! ɛniwʌn u its ɪt ɡɛts sɪk ən daɪz. ðə pipəl woʊn lɪsən. sɛvɹəl ɡɹups tʃɹaɪd tə stɔɹm ðə dɑks fəɹ ðə fud, soʊ aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd nɑt tə lɛɾ əm kɪl ðɛmsɛlvz iɾɪŋ ɪt."

"What have / done?" the man demanded. "I've been trying to keep everyone from rushing those ships for the spoiled food! Anyone who eats it gets sick and dies. The people won't listen. Several groups tried to storm the docks for the food, so I decided not to let them kill themselves eating it."

ðə mænz vɔɪs hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðəɾ æŋɡɹi bɪfɔɹ. mɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪm əz pisəbəl.

The man's voice had never been that angry before. Min remembered him as peaceable.

"leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ flɛɾ ən aʊɝ æftɝ jə lɛft," aɪɹlɪn kəntɪnjud. "ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns ɹæn wɪðɪn ðə deɪ. ðoʊz bɝnɪŋ si foʊk kleɪm ðeɪ woʊn seɪl əweɪ əntɪl ðeɪv ənloʊɾəd ðɛɹ wɛɹz - əɹ əntɪl aɪ ɡɪv əm peɪmən tə də sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. soʊ aɪv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə sɪɾi tə stɑɹv ɪtsɛlf, it ðət fuɾ ən daɪ, əɹ ɡoʊ ʌp ɪn ənʌðɝ ɹaɪəɾ ə fleɪm ən dɛθ. ðæts wʌɾ aɪv bɪn duɪŋ hɪɹ. wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ, lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?"

"Lady Chadmar fled an hour after you left," Iralin continued. "The other members of the Council of Merchants ran within the day. Those burning Sea Folk claim they won't sail away until they've unloaded their wares - or until I give them payment to do something else. So I've been waiting for the city to starve itself, eat that food and die, or go up in another riot of flame and death. That's what I've been doing here. What have you been doing, Lord Dragon?"

ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən saɪd. hi dɪd nɑɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz tə aɪɹlɪn əz i hæd ði ʌðɝz; pɝhæps i sɔ ðəɾ ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv mɛn ɛniθɪŋ.

Rand closed his eyes and sighed. He did not apologize to Iralin as he had the others; perhaps he saw that it would not have meant anything.

mɪn ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ aɪɹlɪn. "hi hæz weɪts əpɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, mɝtʃənt. hi kænɑt wɑtʃ oʊvɝ itʃ ən ɛvɹi - "

Min glared at Iralin. "He has weights upon his shoulders, merchant. He cannot watch over each and every - "

"ɪɾ ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt, mɪn," ɹænd sɛd, leɪɪŋ ɪz hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm ən oʊpənɪŋ ɪz aɪz. "ɪɾ ɪz noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪ dɪzɝv. aɪɹlɪn. bɪfɔɹ aɪ lɛf ðə sɪɾi, jə toʊl mi ðət ðə fuɾ ɑn ðoʊz ʃɪps hæd spɔɪld. dɪd jə tʃɛk ɛvɹi bæɹəl ən sæk?"

"It is all right, Min," Rand said, laying his hand on her arm and opening his eyes. "It is no more than I deserve. Iralin. Before I left the city, you told me that the food on those ships had spoiled. Did you check every barrel and sack?"

"aɪ tʃɛkt ɪnʌf," aɪɹlɪn sɛd, stɪl hɑstəl. "ɪf jə oʊpən ə hʌnʒɹəd sæks ən jə faɪn ðə seɪm θɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi wʌn, jə fɪɡjɝ aʊt ðə pæɾɝn. maɪ waɪf əz bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊɾ ə seɪf mɛθəɾ ə sɪftɪŋ ðə ɹɑɾɪd ɡɹeɪn fɹəm ðə seɪf ɡɹeɪn. ɪf ðɛɹz ɛni seɪf ɡɹeɪn tə bi hæd."

"I checked enough," Iralin said, still hostile. "If you open a hundred sacks and you find the same thing in every one, you figure out the pattern. My wife has been trying to figure out a safe method of sifting the rotted grain from the safe grain. If there's any safe grain to be had."

ɹænd bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ʃɪps. aɪɹlɪn fɑloʊd, lʊkɪŋ kənfjuzd, pɝhæps kəz ɹænd hædn jɛld ət hɪm. mɪn dʒɔɪn ðɛm. ɹænd əpɹoʊtʃt ə si foʊk vɛsəl sɪɾɪŋ loʊ ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ, mʊɹd baɪ ɹoʊps. ə ɡɹup ə si foʊk laʊnʒd ətɑp ɪt.

Rand began walking toward the ships. Iralin followed, looking confused, perhaps because Rand hadn't yelled at him. Min joined them. Rand approached a Sea Folk vessel sitting low in the water, moored by ropes. A group of Sea Folk lounged atop it.

"wʌn wəd spik wɪð jəɹ seɪlməstʃɹəs," ɹænd kɔld.

"1 would speak with your Sailmistress," Rand called.

"aɪ æm ʃi," sɛd wʌn ə ðə si foʊk, ə wʊmən wɪð waɪɾ ɪn əɹ stʃɹeɪt blæk hɛɹ ən ə pæɾɝn ə tætuz əkɹɔs əɹ ɹaɪt hænd. "maɪlɪs dɪn ʃəlɑɾə θɹi stɑɹz."

"I am she," said one of the Sea Folk, a woman with white in her straight black hair and a pattern of tattoos across her right hand. "milis din Shalada Three Stars."

"aɪ meɪɾ ə dil," ɹænd kɔld ʌp, "fɔɹ fud tə bi dɪlɪvɝd hɪɹ."

"I made a deal," Rand called up, "for food to be delivered here."

"ðæt wʌn dʌznt wɑn ɪt dɪlɪvɝd," maɪlɪs sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə aɪɹlɪn. "hi woʊn lɛɾ əs ənloʊd; sɛz ðəɾ ɪf wi du, hɪl əv ɪz ɑɹtʃɝz lus ɑn ʌs."

"That one doesn't want it delivered," Milis said, nodding to Iralin. "He won't let us unload; says that if we do, he'll have his archers loose on us."

"aɪ wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə hoʊl ðə pipəl bæk," aɪɹlɪn sɛd. "aɪv hæd tə spɹɛd ɹumɝz ɪn taʊn ðət ðə si foʊk ɑɹ hoʊldɪŋ ðə fud hɑstɪdʒ."

"I wouldn't be able to hold the people back," Iralin said. "I've had to spread rumors in town that the Sea Folk are holding the food hostage."

"ju si wʌt wi sʌfɝ fəɹ ju?" maɪlɪs sɛd tə ɹænd. "aɪ bɪɡɪn tə wʌndɝ əbaʊɾ əɹ bɑɹɡən wɪð ju, ɹænd ælθɹ."

"You see what we suffer for you?" Milis said to Rand. "I begin to wonder about our Bargain with you, Rand al'Thor."

"du jə dɪnaɪ ðəɾ aɪm ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ?" ɹænd æskt, miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz. ʃi sim tə hæv tʃɹʌbəl lʊkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm.

"Do you deny that I am the Coramoor?" Rand asked, meeting her eyes. She seemed to have trouble looking away from him.

"noʊ," maɪlɪs sɛd. "noʊ, ɡɛs ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt. jəl wɑnə bɔɹd ðə waɪtkæp, aɪ səpoʊz."

"No," Milis said. "No, guess that I do not. You will want to board the Whitecap, I suppose."

"ɪf aɪ meɪ."

"If I may."

"ʌp wɪð ju, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd.

"Up with you, then," she said.

Instead, he placed her at the back, surrounded by Wise Ones and Cha Faile, accompanied by Aes Sedai.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪpt ɪz ɹeɪnz taɪɾɝ, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə mɑɹtʃɪŋ fit. fju ʌv ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz hæɾ ɑɹmɝ.

Perrin gripped his reins tighter, listening to the marching feet. Few of the refugees had armor.

ɑɹɡændə hæd kɔld əm laɪɾ ɪnfəntʃɹi. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ənʌðɝ tɝm fəɹ ðɛm: "ɪnəsəns wɪð bleɪdz."

Arganda had called them light infantry. Perrin had another term for them: "innocents with blades."

waɪ dɪd ðeɪ fɑloʊ hɪm? kʊdn ðeɪ si ðət ðeɪ wəd fɔl fɝst?

Why did they follow him? Couldn't they see that they would fall first?

ðeɪ tʃɹʌstɪd hɪm. laɪt bɝn ðɛm, ðeɪ ɔl tʃɹʌstɪd hɪm! hi ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz hæmɝ, smɛlɪŋ ðə dæmp ɛɹ mɪkst wɪð fɪɹ ən ɪksaɪtmənt. ðə θʌndɝ ə hʊvz ən fʊtstɛps, ɹimaɪndɪŋ ɪm ə ðə dɑɹk skaɪ. θʌndɝ wɪð noʊ laɪtnɪŋ. laɪtnɪŋ wɪð noʊ θʌndɝ.

They trusted him. Light burn them, they all trusted him! He rested his hand on his hammer, smelling the damp air mixed with fear and excitement. The thunder of hooves and footsteps, reminding him of the dark sky. Thunder with no lightning. Lightning with no thunder.

ðə bæɾəlfild wɑz əhɛd, ə bɹɔd ɡɹin ɡɹæslæn laɪn ɑn ðə fɑɹ ɛn baɪ tʃɹups ɪn waɪt. ðət waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi wɔɹ sɪlvɝ bɹɛstpleɪts ʃaɪn tə pɝfɛkʃən, ðɛɹ tɑbɝdz ən kloʊks ə pjʊɹ waɪt.

The battlefield was ahead, a broad green grassland lined on the far end by troops in white. That Whitecloak army wore silver breastplates shined to perfection, their tabards and cloaks a pure white.

ðɪs ɡɹæsi pleɪn wɑz ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə hæv ə bæɾəl. ɪt wəɾ ɔlsoʊ bi ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə plæn kɹɑps.

This grassy plain was a good place to have a battle. It would also be a good place to plant crops.

tə ʌndɝstæn ə θɪŋ, jə mʌst ʌndɝstæn ɪts pɑɹts ən ɪts pɝpəs.

To understand a thing, you must understand its parts and its purpose.

wʌt hæd bɪn ðə pɝpəs ə hɪz wɔɹ æks? tə kɪl. ðət wɑz waɪ ɪt hæd bɪn meɪd. ðət wɑz ɔl ɪt hæd bɪn ɡʊd fɔɹ.

What had been the purpose of his war axe? To kill. That was why it had been made. That was all it had been good for.

bʌt ðə hæmɝ wɑz dɪfɹənt.

But the hammer was different.

pɛɹɪn pʊl stɛpɝ ʌp ʃɑɹpli. bɪsaɪd hɪm, ði æʃəmən stɑpt, ən ði ɪntaɪɝ kɑləm ə tʃɹups stɑɹɾəd tə pʊl tə ə hɔlt. ɡɹups bʌntʃt ʌp əz ðeɪ sloʊd; jɛld ɔɹɾɝz ɹipleɪs ðə saʊnz ə mɑɹtʃɪŋ.

Perrin pulled Stepper up sharply. Beside him, the Asha'man stopped, and the entire column of troops started to pull to a halt. Groups bunched up as they slowed; yelled orders replaced the sounds of marching.

ði ɛɹ wɑz stɪl, ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd dʒɹɪɹi. hi kʊdn smɛl ðə ɡɹæs əɹ ðə dɪstən tʃɹiz fəɹ ðə dʌst ɪn ði ɛɹ ən ðə mɛn swɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ. hɔɹsəz snɔɹɾɪd, ə nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm nɪbəlɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹæs. ʌðɝz ʃʌfəld, kætʃɪŋ ðə tɛnʃən ə ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz.

The air was still, the sky overhead dreary. He couldn't smell the grass or the distant trees for the dust in the air and the men sweating in their armor. Horses snorted, a number of them nibbling at the grass. Others shuffled, catching the tension of their riders.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ɡɹeɪɾi æskt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"My Lord?" Grady asked. "What is it?"

ðə waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn pəzɪʃən wɪð ə vi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə ɹaɪɾɝz ət ðə fɹʌnt. ðeɪ weɪɾəd, lænsɪz əpɹaɪt, ɹɛɾi tə bi loʊɝd tə spɪl blʌd.

The Whitecloak army was already in position with a V formation of riders at the front. They waited, lances upright, ready to be lowered to spill blood.

"ði æks oʊnli kɪlz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌt ðə hæmɝ kən iðɝ kɹieɪɾ əɹ kɪl. ðəɾ ɪz ðə dɪfɝəns."

"The axe only kills," Perrin said. "But the hammer can either create or kill. That is the difference."

ɪt meɪd sɛns tə hɪm, sʌɾənli. ðət wɑz waɪ hid niɾəd tə θɹoʊ ði æks əweɪ. hi kəd tʃuz nɑt tə kɪl. hi wəd nɑt bi pʊʃt ɪndə ðɪs.

It made sense to him, suddenly. That was why he'd needed to throw the axe away. He could choose not to kill. He would not be pushed into this.

hi tɝn tə ɡɔl, hu stʊd wɪð sɛvɹəl meɪɾənz ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. "aɪ wɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz ʌp hɪɹ naʊ." pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ɔɹɾɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ æsk ðə waɪz wʌnz. ɔɹɾɝ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ʌp əz wɛl."

He turned to Gaul, who stood with several Maidens a short distance away. "I want the Aes Sedai and Wise Ones up here now." Perrin hesitated. "Order the Aes Sedai, but ask the Wise Ones. Order the Two Rivers men up as well."

ɡɔl nɑɾəd ən ɹæn tə də əz æskt. pɛɹɪn tɝn bæk tə ðə waɪt-kloʊks. fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ fɔls, ðə waɪtkloʊks kənsɪɾɝd ðɛmsɛlvz ɑnɝəbəl. ðeɪ wʊdn ətæk əntɪl pɛɹɪn wɑz ɪn pəzɪʃən.

Gaul nodded and ran to do as asked. Perrin turned back to the White-cloaks. For all their faults, the Whitecloaks considered themselves honorable. They wouldn't attack until Perrin was in position.

ðə klʌstɝ ʌv waɪz wʌnz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ dʒɔɪn ɪm ət ðə fɹʌnt. feɪl, hi noʊɾəst, ɹoʊd wɪð ðɛm.

The cluster of Wise Ones and Aes Sedai joined him at the front. Faile, he noticed, rode with them.

wɛl, hi hæd toʊld əɹ tə steɪ wɪð ðɛm. hi hɛld aʊɾ ə hæn tə hɝ, ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ əɹ nɛks tə hɪm. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn keɪm ʌp ɑn ðə flæŋk ə hɪz fɔɹs.

Well, he had told her to stay with them. He held out a hand to her, inviting her next to him. The Two Rivers men came up on the flank of his force.

"ɡɔl sɛd jə wɝ vɛɹi pəlaɪt," ɛdʒɹə noʊɾəd tə pɛɹɪn. "ðæt minz jə wɑn sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm əs ðət wɪl nɑt wɑnə du."

"Gaul said you were very polite," Edarra noted to Perrin. "That means you want something from us that we will not want to do."

pɛɹɪn smaɪld. "aɪ wɑn jə tə hɛlp mi pɹɪvɛn ðɪs bæɾəl."

Perrin smiled. "I want you to help me prevent this battle."

jə də nɑt wɪʃ tə dæns ðə spɪɹz?" ɛdʒɹə æskt. "aɪ hæv hɝd səm ʌv wʌt ðiz mɛn ɪn waɪɾ əv dʌn ɪn ðə wɛtlænz. aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ wɛɹɹ waɪt tə haɪd wʌɾ ɪz dɑɹk ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðɛm."

You do not wish to dance the spears?" Edarra asked. "I have heard some of what these men in white have done in the wetlands. I think they wearr white to hide what is dark inside of them."

"ðeɪɹ kənfjuzd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɛl, ðəɹ mɔɹ ðən kənfjuzd. ðəɹ laɪt-kɝs fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ. bʌt wi ʃʊdn bi faɪɾɪŋ ðɛm, nɑt wɪð ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmɪŋ. ɪf wi skwɑbəl əmʌŋ aʊɝsɛlvz, wɪl luz tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

"They're confused," Perrin said. "Well, they're more than confused. They're Light-cursed frustrating. But we shouldn't be fighting them, not with the Last Battle coming. If we squabble among ourselves, we will lose to the Dark One."

ɛdʒɹə læft. "aɪ wəd laɪk tə si sʌmwʌn tɛl ðət tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. ɔɹəɡən, ɹæðɝ, aɪ wəd laɪk tə hæv sin sʌmwʌn sədʒɛs ðət tə jə wən ðeɪ stɪl hɛl jəɹ waɪf!"

Edarra laughed. "I would like to see someone tell that to the Shaido, Perrin Aybara. Or, rather, I would like to have seen someone suggest that to you when they still held your wife!"

"wɛl, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ niɾəd kɪlɪŋ," hi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðiz waɪtkloʊks du. meɪbi ðeɪ oʊnli niɾ ə ɡʊd fɹaɪt. aɪ wɑn jə ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə blæs ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmi."

"Well, the Shaido needed killing," he said. "But I don't know if these Whitecloaks do. Maybe they only need a good fright. I want you and the Aes Sedai to blast the ground in front of their army."

"ju æsk sʌmθɪŋ jə ʃəd nɑt, eɪbɑɹə," siɑnɪd sɛd stɝnli. "wi wɪl nɑt teɪk pɑɹɾ ɪn jəɹ bæɾəl. ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv ɡɹin mɛɾ ɪz aɪz, vɔɪs kɹɪsp ən kɝt.

"You ask something you should not, Aybara," Seonid said sternly. "We will not take part in your battle. The diminutive Green met his eyes, voice crisp and curt.

"jɔɹ nɑt teɪkɪŋ pɑɹɾ ɪn bæɾəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ pɹɪvɛntɪŋ wʌn."

"You're not taking part in battle," Perrin said. "You're preventing one."

siɑnɪd fɹaʊnd. "aɪm əfɹeɪɾ ɪt wəd bi ðə seɪm, ɪn ðɪs keɪs. ɪf wi ətæk ði ɝθ, ɪt wəd bi juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən. wi kəd hɝt ðoʊz mɛn. aɪm sɑɹi."

Seonid frowned. "I'm afraid it would be the same, in this case. If we attack the earth, it would be using the One Power as a weapon. We could hurt those men. I'm sorry."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ, bʌt dɪd nɑt fɔɹs ðɛm. ðə waɪz wʌnz ən æʃəmən wəd pɹɑbli bi ɪnʌf. hi tɝn tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. "tɑɹn, tɛl ðə mɛn tə nɑk æɹoʊz ən bi ɹɛɾi tə lɔntʃ ə vɑli."

Perrin ground his teeth, but did not force them. The Wise Ones and Asha'man would probably be enough. He turned to the Two Rivers men. "Tarn, tell the men to nock arrows and be ready to launch a volley."

tɑɹn nɑɾəd, sɛndɪŋ ə ɹʌnɝ wɪð ði ɔɹɾɝ. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn laɪn ʌp. ðɪs wɑz bɪɑn ðə ɹeɪnʒ ə moʊs baʊz, bʌɾ ə ɡʊd pʊl ɑn ə tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊ kəd mænədʒ ɪt.

Tarn nodded, sending a runner with the order. The Two Rivers men lined up. This was beyond the range of most bows, but a good pull on a Two Rivers longbow could manage it.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd tə ðə waɪz wʌnz, ðən moʊʃən təwɔɹd ði æʃəmən. bɪfɔɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls kəd bi sɛd, ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə waɪtkloʊks ɪɹʌptəd. ə ɹʌmbəl ʃʊk ðə mɛdoʊ, dɝɾ ɪksploʊɾɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil muv ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz fɔɹwɝd.

Perrin nodded to the Wise Ones, then motioned toward the Asha'man. Before anything else could be said, the ground in front of the Whitecloaks erupted. A rumble shook the meadow, dirt exploding into the air. Grady and Neald moved their horses forward.

ðə waɪtkloʊks' hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹɾ ən mɛn ʃaʊɾəd ɪn tɛɹɝ. ə smɔl ɡɹup ə mɛn ət ðə vɛɹi fɹʌn dɪdn sim dɪstɝbd baɪ ði ɪksploʊʒənz, ən ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. ðoʊz wəd bi ðə liɾɝz. ɪndid, pɛɹɪnz aɪz kəd meɪk aʊt ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ hɪmsɛlf sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ.

The Whitecloaks' horses reared and men shouted in terror. A small group of men at the very front didn't seem disturbed by the explosions, and they kept their horses under control. Those would be the leaders. Indeed, Perrin's eyes could make out the Lord Captain Commander himself sitting there.

dɝt spɹeɪɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ əɡɛn, fɔlɪŋ tə pɛl ðə tʃɹɛntʃ bɪniθ. ðə waɪz wʌnz wɔɹ ðət lʊk ə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən ðət keɪm wɪð tʃænəlɪŋ.

Dirt sprayed into the air again, falling to pelt the trench beneath. The Wise Ones wore that look of concentration that came with channeling.

"kæn wʌn ə jə ɛnhæns maɪ vɔɪs?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Can one of you enhance my voice?" Perrin asked.

"aɪ kən də ɪt," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. "aɪ sɔ ðə l də ɪt wʌns."

"I can do it," Grady said. "I saw the M'Hael do it once."

"ɡʊd," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə tɑɹn. "wʌns ðə tʃænlɝz stɑp, tɛl ðə mɛn tə ɡɪmi ə kʌpəl ə lɔŋ vɑliz. tʃɹaɪ ən hɪt ðət tʃɹɛntʃ."

"Good," Perrin said, turning to Tarn. "Once the channelers stop, tell the men to give me a couple of long volleys. Try and hit that trench."

ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ, ði ɪksploʊʒənz ɛndəd. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn dʒɹu ə vɑli ən lust ɪt.

A few moments later, the explosions ended. The Two Rivers men drew a volley and loosed it.

θɪk ʃæfs ɹoʊz ɪn ən ɑɹk, ən sun ðə ɹɪf bɹɪsəld wɪð æɹoʊz. pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt ðə waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi. ðeɪ hæd bɹoʊkən ɹæŋks, stændɪŋ ɪn dɪsɔɹɾɝ.

Thick shafts rose in an arc, and soon the rift bristled with arrows. Perrin watched the Whitecloak army. They had broken ranks, standing in disorder.

ə klæŋk ʌv ɑɹmɝ mætʃt baɪ hʊfbits ənaʊnst ɑɹɡændəz ɝaɪvəl.

A clank of armor matched by hoofbeats announced Arganda's arrival.

ðə fɝs kæptən ʌv ɡildən wɔɹ ɪz plum hɛlm, hɪz aɪz hɑɹd bɪniθ ɪt. "wʌt wɑz ðə pɔɪn ə ðæt, ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə?" hi smɛld ɛfii "ju dʒʌst ɡeɪv əweɪ əɹ ædvæntɪdʒ! ən æmbʊʃ cʊɾə kɪl θaʊzənz ən bɹoʊkən ðɛɹ ɪnɪʃəl tʃɑɹdʒ."

The First Captain of Ghealdan wore his plumed helm, his eyes hard beneath it. "What was the point of that, if I may ask, Lord Aybara?" He smelled f;ie "You just gave away our advantage! An ambush could have killed thousands and broken their initial charge."

"jɛs " pɛɹɪn sɛd. feɪl stɪl ɹoʊɾ əɾ ɪz ʌðɝ saɪd. "æn ðeɪ noʊ ɪt. lʊk ət ðɛɹ laɪnz, ɑɹɡændə. ðəɹ wɝid. ðə waɪtkloʊks ɑɹ ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ðeɪɾ əv tə ɡoʊ θɹu tə tʃɑɹdʒ ʌs.

"Yes " Perrin said. Faile still rode at his other side. "And they know it. Look at their lines, Arganda. They're worried. The Whitecloaks are realizing what they'd have to go through to charge us.

ɪf aɪ wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv əm ðɪs əz ə wɔɹnɪŋ bɝst, wʌt wɑz aɪ hoʊldɪŋ bæk?"

If I was willing to give them this as a warning burst, what was I holding back?"

"bʌt ðət wɑz ði ɪkstɛn ʌv wʌt wi kən du," feɪl sɛd.

"But that was the extent of what we can do," Faile said.

"ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ ðæt." pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪnd. "ɪt wəd bi stupəɾ ʌv əs tə kəmɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪv ɪn ə wɔɹnɪŋ blæs laɪk ðæt."

"They don't know that." Perrin grinned. "It would be stupid of us to commit everything we have in a warning blast like that."

ɑɹɡændə hɛld ɪz tʌŋ, ðoʊ hi ɑbviəsli wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ðət vɛɹi θɪŋ. hi wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ tə ðə boʊn. ən æks. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ðæt, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd tə bi ðə hæmɝ. wən i pɔɪntəd, mɛn laɪk ɑɹɡændə kɪld.

Arganda held his tongue, though he obviously was thinking that very thing. He was a soldier to the bone. An axe. There was nothing wrong with that, but Perrin had to be the hammer. When he pointed, men like Arganda killed.

"ɡɹeɪɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "maɪ vɔɪs, pliz? aɪ wʊdn maɪn ɪf əɹ ɑɹmi kəd hɪɹ wʌɾ aɪ seɪ, tu."

"Grady," Perrin said. "My voice, please? I wouldn't mind if our army could hear what I say, too."

"aɪ kən mænədʒ ðæt," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd.

"I can manage that," Grady said.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən spoʊk. "aɪ æm pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə!" hɪz vɔɪs bumd əkɹɔs ðə pleɪn. "aɪ æm fɹɛn tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən aɪ sɝv hɪɹ əɾ ɪz kəmænd. aɪm mɑɹtʃɪŋ tə ðə læs bæɾəl.

Perrin took a deep breath, then spoke. "I am Perrin Aybara!" his voice boomed across the plain. "I am friend to the Dragon Reborn, and I serve here at his command. I am marching to the Last Battle.

lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, jə dɪmændəɾ aɪ mit wɪð jə ɑn jəɹ tɝmz bɪfɔɹ, ən aɪ keɪm. aɪ æsk jə tə ɹɪtɝn ði ɑnɝ hɪɹ, ən miɾ əz aɪ ɹɪkwɛst. ɪf jə ɑɹ dɪtɝmən tə kɪl mi bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ, ət lis də mi ðə sɝvəs ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ mi wʌn læs tʃæns tə pɹɪvɛn spɪlɪŋ blʌd ðɪs deɪ!"

Lord Captain Commander, you demanded I meet with you on your terms before, and I came. I ask you to return the honor here, and meet as I request. If you are determined to kill me before I ride against the Shadow, at least do me the service of giving me one last chance to prevent spilling blood this day!"

hi nɑɾəd tə ɡɹeɪɾi, ən ðə mæn ɹilist ɪz wiv. "du wɪv ə pəvɪljən wi kəd sɛɾ ʌp fəɹ pɑɹli?"

He nodded to Grady, and the man released his weave. "Do we have a pavilion we could set up for parley?"

"bæk ət ðə kæmp," feɪl sɛd.

"Back at the camp," Faile said.

"aɪ kən tʃɹaɪ ə ɡeɪtweɪ," nil sɛd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃ - ɔɹ, ət list, ðə θɪn bɪɾ ə fɝ ɑn ɪz feɪs ðəɾ i kɔld ə mʌstæʃ, wæks tə pɔɪns.

"I can try a gateway," Neald said, knuckling his mustache - or, at least, the thin bit of fur on his face that he called a mustache, waxed to points.

"tʃɹaɪ ɪt."

"Try it."

hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd. nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. ðə jʌŋ mæn blʌʃt fjʊɹiəsli. "dʌznt wɝk. nɑt tʃɹævlɪŋ əɹ skɪmɪŋ."

He concentrated. Nothing happened. The young man blushed furiously. "Doesn't work. Not Traveling or Skimming."

aɪ si," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɛl, lɛts sɛn ə ɹaɪɾɝ bæk. wi ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə hæv ðə tɛn sɛɾ ʌp hɪɹ ɪn mɪnəts. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðəl əɡɹi tə mit, bʌɾ aɪ wɑnə ɡɛt ɹɛɾi, ɪn keɪs ðeɪ du. bɹɪŋ bɹəleɪn ən æliændɝ bæk əz wɛl, ən pɝhæps sʌmwʌn wɪð dʒɹɪŋks ən ðə tʃɛɹz ən teɪbəl fɹəm maɪ tɛnt."

I see," Perrin said. "Well, let's send a rider back. We should be able to have the tent set up here in minutes. I don't know if they'll agree to meet, but I want to get ready, in case they do. Bring Berelain and Alliandre back as well, and perhaps someone with drinks and the chairs and table from my tent."

ðə pɹɑpɝ ɔɹɾɝz wɝ ɡɪvən, ən ə tu ɹɪvɝz mæn - ɹɑb soʊltɝ-ɹoʊɾ ɔf, meɪɾənz tʃɹeɪlɪŋ æftɝ hɪm. ðə waɪtkloʊks sim tə bi kɑn-saɪɾɝɪŋ ɪz pɹɑpəzɪʃən. ɡʊd.

The proper orders were given, and a Two Rivers man - Robb Solter-rode off, Maidens trailing after him. The Whitecloaks seemed to be con-sidering his proposition. Good.

ɑɹɡændə ən moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz spɹɛɾ aʊt tə pæs ðə wɝɾ əbaʊt wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, ðoʊ ðeɪ kʊdn pɑsəbli hæv mɪs pɛɹɪnz ənaʊnsmənt. ɛvɹiwʌn sim tə bi duɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ʃʊd, soʊ pɛɹɪn sæt bæk ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə weɪt.

Arganda and most of the others spread out to pass the word about what was happening, though they couldn't possibly have missed Perrin's announcement. Everyone seemed to be doing what they should, so Perrin sat back in his saddle to wait.

feɪl saɪɾəld əɹ hɔɹs ʌp tə hɪm. ʃi smɛld ɪntʃɹiɡd.

Faile sidled her horse up to him. She smelled intrigued.

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What?" Perrin asked.

"sʌmθɪŋz tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊt ju. aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt."

"Something's changed about you. I'm trying to figure out what."

"aɪm stɔlɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ hævən meɪɾ ɛni dɪsɪʒənz jɛt. bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑnə kɪl ðiz mɛn.

"I'm stalling," Perrin said. "I haven't made any decisions yet. But I don't want to kill these men.

nɑt jɛt. nɑɾ ənlɛs aɪ hæv tə."

Not yet. Not unless I have to."

"ðeɪɹ nɑt gɑnə ɡɪv ɛni ɡɹaʊnd, hʌzbənd," feɪl sɛd. "ðeɪv ɔlɹɛɾi dʒʌdʒ ju."

"They're not going to give any ground, husband," Faile said. "They've already judged you."

"wil si," hi sɛd. hi lʊkt ʌp ət ðə skaɪ, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɛn ən ðə fæk ðət ði æʃəmən ɡeɪtweɪz wɝnt wɝkɪŋ. sleɪɝ wɑz pɹaʊlɪŋ ðɪs ɛɹiə ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ən ðəɹ wɑz ðət wɔl ʌv ɡlæs. sʌmθɪŋ fɛl vɛɹi ɹɔŋ ɑn ðə wɪnd, ən ɪz sɛnsɪz ɪtʃt ət hɪm. bi wɛɹi. bi pɹipɛɹd.

"We'll see," he said. He looked up at the sky, thinking of the strange scent and the fact that the Asha'man gateways weren't working. Slayer was prowling this area in the wolf dream and there was that wall of glass. Something felt very wrong on the wind, and his senses itched at him. Be wary. Be prepared.

ðə hæmɝ kəd kɪl əɹ kɹieɪt. hi dɪdnt noʊ wɪtʃ sɪtʃueɪʃən ðɪs wɑz jɛt. hi dɪdn ɪntɛn tə stʃɹaɪk əntɪl i dɪd.

The hammer could kill or create. He didn't know which situation this was yet. He didn't intend to strike until he did.

ɡɑləd sæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹæsi pleɪn ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn ə fild ə bæɾəl, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə tʃɹɛntʃ tɔɹn ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bɹɪsəlɪŋ wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ʌv æɹoʊz.

Galad sat on the grassy plain that should have been a field of battle, looking at the trench torn in the ground, bristling with hundreds of arrows.

hi wɑz pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt hɝt sʌmwʌn ənlɛs ʃi əɹ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ, ən ɡɑləd hæd ɡɪvən vɛɹi spəsɪfɪk ɔɹɾɝz tə hɪz pipəl nɑt tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ - əɹ ivən ɡoʊ nɪɹ  - ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf ðə tʃɪlʒɹən sɔ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðeɪ wɝ tə stɑp ən nɑd ðɛɹ hɛdz, tɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛpənz əweɪ. ɪf ɪz mɛn ʃoʊd pleɪnli ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt hɑɹm ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðən ðə sɪstɝz ʃəd bi jusləs ɪn bæɾəl.

He was prepared for Aes Sedai. An Aes Sedai could not hurt someone unless she or her Warder was in danger, and Galad had given very specific orders to his people not to engage - or even go near  - Aes Sedai. If the Children saw Aes Sedai, they were to stop and nod their heads, turning their weapons away. If his men showed plainly that they would not harm Aes Sedai, then the sisters should be useless in battle.

mɛni ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən dɪd nɑt bɪliv ðɪs. ðeɪ kɔl ðə stɔɹiz ə ðə θɹi oʊðz dɪlɪbɝɪt fæbɹɪkeɪʃənz. ðeɪ hædn lɪvd ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɡɑləd dɪdn laɪk moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən i sɝɾənli dɪdn tʃɹʌs ðɛm, bʌɾ i nu ðət ði oʊðz dɪd hoʊld.

Many of the Children did not believe this. They called the stories of the Three Oaths deliberate fabrications. They hadn't lived in the White Tower. Galad didn't like most Aes Sedai, and he certainly didn't trust them, but he knew that the oaths did hold.

ɡɑləɾ ɛs mɛn muv bæk ɪndə laɪn, mʌɾɝɪŋ. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, ɪnspɛktɪŋ eɪbɑɹəz fɹʌn laɪn. mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts. sɛvɹəl il wɪmən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd kʌm wɪð eɪbɑɹə tə ðɛɹ fɝs miɾɪŋz. ə tʃænlɝ, noʊ daʊt. hi ɪmædʒən ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪksploʊɾɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ fɔɹsɪz, nɑkɪŋ ðə kævəlɹi ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ʌðɝz fɔlɪŋ ɪndə ðə tʃɹɛntʃ waɪl ðə leɪɾɝ laɪnz stɔld ɪn kənfjuʒən, pɹeɪ tə ðoʊz aɪm-pɹɛsɪv lɔŋboʊz.

Galad s men moved back into line, muttering. He raised his looking glass, inspecting Aybara's front line. Men in black coats. Several Aiel women, including one of those who had come with Aybara to their first meetings. A channeler, no doubt. He imagined the ground exploding beneath his charging forces, knocking the cavalry into the air, others falling into the trench while the later lines stalled in confusion, prey to those im-pressive longbows.

bɔɹnhəld ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ɡɑləd, hɪz feɪs æŋɡɹi. "wi ɑɹən ɹɪli ɡoʊɪŋ tə pɑɹli, ɑɹ wi?"

Bornhald rode up to Galad, his face angry. "We aren't really going to parley, are we?"

ɡɑləd loʊɝɾ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. "jɛs. aɪ θɪŋk wi ɑɹ."

Galad lowered his looking glass. "Yes. I think we are."

"bʌt wi ɔlɹɛɾi mɛt wɪð hɪm!" bɔɹnhəl sɛd. "ju sɛd jə wɑntəd tə si ðoʊz aɪz, əz pɹuf i wɑz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, ən jə sɔ ðɛm. wʌt mɔɹ dʒju nid?"

"But we already met with him!" Bornhald said. "You said you wanted to see those eyes, as proof he was Shadowspawn, and you saw them. What more do you need?"

baɪɑɝ sɛd, nʌdʒɪŋ ɪz maʊn kloʊsɝ. hi ɔfən æktəɾ əz ə ɡɑɹd tə ɡɑləd ðiz deɪz. "hi kæn bi tʃɹʌstɪd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ."

Byar said, nudging his mount closer. He often acted as a guard to Galad these days. "He can't be trusted, my Lord Captain Commander."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd ət ðə tʃɹɛntʃ. "hi cʊɾə dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ əs wɪð ðəɾ ətæk."

Galad nodded at the trench. "He could have destroyed us with that attack."

"aɪ əɡɹi wɪð baɪɑɝ," bɔɹnhəl sɛd. "hi wɑns tə dʒɹɔ jə aʊt, ðən kɪl jə tə dɪmɔɹəlaɪz ʌs."

"I agree with Byar," Bornhald said. "He wants to draw you out, then kill you to demoralize us."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd sloʊli. "ðæts pɑsəbəl." hi tɝn tə lɔɹd kæptən hɑɹnɪʃ, hu ɹoʊd nɪɹbaɪ.

Galad nodded slowly. "That's possible." He turned to Lord Captain Harnesh, who rode nearby.

"ɪf aɪ daɪ, aɪ wɑn jə tə teɪk kəmæn ən tʃɑɹdʒ. ətæk wɪθaʊt mɝsi; aɪ ɹɪpil maɪ ɔɹɾɝ tə əvɔɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. kɪl ɛniwʌn u simz tə bi tʃænəlɪŋ. meɪk ɪɾ ə pɹaɪɔɹəɾi. ɪts pɑsəbəl ðət wi də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ hɪɹ."

"If I die, I want you to take command and charge. Attack without mercy; I repeal my order to avoid Aes Sedai. Kill anyone who seems to be channeling. Make it a priority. It's possible that we do not understand what is happening here."

"bʌt jəɹ stɪl ɡoʊɪŋ?" bɔɹnhəld æskt.

"But you're still going?" Bornhald asked.

"jɛs," ɡɑləd sɛd. hi hæd lɛt bɔɹnhəld ən baɪɑɝ ɡoʊɾ ɪm ɪndə bæɾəl, bʌt naʊ hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf hid bɪn tu heɪsti. hi hæd sin ðoʊz aɪz, ən hæd hɝd ðə tɛstəmoʊniz ə boʊθ ɪz tʃɪlʒɹən ən səm ə ðoʊz u hæd ɹɪɾən wɪð eɪbɑɹə. ɪt hæd sim klɪɹ ðəɾ ətækɪŋ wɑz ðə θɪŋ tə du.

"Yes," Galad said. He had let Bornhald and Byar goad him into battle, but now he wondered if he'd been too hasty. He had seen those eyes, and had heard the testimonies of both his Children and some of those who had ridden with Aybara. It had seemed clear that attacking was the thing to do.

bʌɾ eɪbɑɹə wɑz ɹaɪt. hi hæd kʌm tə mit wɪð ɡɑləd wən æskt. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ tə pɹɪvɛn blʌdʃɛd. ɡɑləd dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ivən ə tʃæns, ðən dɪleɪɪŋ wɑz ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ. ɪt wɑz əz sɪmpəl əz ðæt.

But Aybara was right. He had come to meet with Galad when asked. Perhaps there was a way to prevent bloodshed. Galad did not believe it, but if there was even a chance, then delaying was the right thing. It was as simple as that.

bɔɹnhəl dɪd nɑt sim plizd. hɪz æŋɡɝ ət ðə mæn u hæd kɪld ɪz fɑðɝ wɑz ʌndɝstændəbəl, bʌɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɡaɪd ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. "ju meɪ kʌm wɪð mi," ɡɑləd sɛd, nʌdʒɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd. "ðæt ɡoʊz fəɹ jə əz wɛl, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. ðə lɔɹdz kæptən ʃəd ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd, skæɾɝd θɹu ðə mɛn, lɛst eɪbɑɹə liv əs wɪθaʊt liɾɝz."

Bornhald did not seem pleased. His anger at the man who had killed his father was understandable, but it could not be allowed to guide the Children. "You may come with me," Galad said, nudging his horse forward. "That goes for you as well, Child Byar. The Lords Captain should remain behind, scattered through the men, lest Aybara leave us without leaders."

hɑɹnɪʃ səluɾəd. bɔɹnhəld ɹɪlʌktənli fɛl ɪndə pleɪs bɪsaɪd ɡɑləd, əz dɪd baɪɑɝ, huz aɪz bɝnd wɪð ə waɪl zil ðət mætʃt bɔɹnhəld ɛs æŋɡɝ.

Harnesh saluted. Bornhald reluctantly fell into place beside Galad, as did Byar, whose eyes burned with a wild zeal that matched Bornhald s anger.

boʊθ hæɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns dɪfiɾ ən ɪndɪɡnəɾi ət ðə hænz ə ðɪs pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. ɡɑləɾ ɔlsoʊ tʊk fɪfti tʃɪlʒɹən əz ɡɑɹdz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn fɔɹmeɪʃən bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Both had experienced defeat and indignity at the hands of this Perrin Aybara. Galad also took fifty Children as guards, riding in formation behind him.

ə pəvɪljən wɑz sɛɾ ʌp baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɝaɪvd. flæt tɑpt ən sɪmpəl, ɪt hæd fɔɹ poʊlz stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ðə bɹaʊnɪʃ ɡɹeɪ kænvəs. ðəɹ wɑz ə smɔl skwɛɹ teɪbəl ʌndɝ ɪt, əkʌmpənid baɪ tu tʃɛɹz.

A pavilion was set up by the time they arrived. Flat topped and simple, it had four poles stretching the brownish gray canvas. There was a small square table under it, accompanied by two chairs.

eɪbɑɹə sæɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə teɪbəl. hi stʊɾ ʌp əz ɡɑləɾ əpɹoʊtʃt; tədeɪ, ðə lɑɹdʒ mæn wɔɹ ə ɡɹin koʊɾ ən bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz - boʊθ wɛl kɹæftɪd bʌt pleɪn - ən hæd ðət hæmɝ slʌŋ əɾ ɪz weɪst. ðə kloʊðz hæɾ ən ɝθi sɛnsɪbɪlɪɾi tə ðɛm. noʊ, ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə mæn ə pæləsəz bʌɾ ə mæn ə filz ən fɔɹəsts. ə wʊdzmən u hæd ɹɪzən tə bi ə lɔɹd.

Aybara sat on one side of the table. He stood up as Galad approached; today, the large man wore a green coat and brown trousers - both well crafted but plain - and had that hammer slung at his waist. The clothes had an earthy sensibility to them. No, this was not a man of palaces but a man of fields and forests. A woodsman who had risen to be a lord.

ə pɛɹ ə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn stʊɾ ət ðə bæk ə ðə pəvɪljən, hoʊldɪŋ paʊɝfəl tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊz. ðeɪ wɝ sɛd tə bi ɪndɪpɛndən fɑɹmɝz ən hɝdzmɪn ʌv oʊld, stɝɾi stɑk. ən ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən ðɪs pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə tə lid ðɛm.

A pair of Two Rivers men stood at the back of the pavilion, holding powerful Two Rivers longbows. They were said to be independent farmers and herdsmen of old, sturdy stock. And they had chosen this Perrin Aybara to lead them.

ɡɑləd wɔk təwɔɹd ðə pəvɪljən. baɪɑɝ ən bɔɹnhəl dʒɔɪn ɪm ðoʊ ði ʌðɝ fɪfti ɹɪmeɪn maʊntəɾ aʊtsaɪd.

Galad walked toward the pavilion. Byar and Bornhald joined him though the other fifty remained mounted outside.

ənlaɪk ðɛɹ læs miɾɪŋ, ðəɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ, θɹi hum i kəd spɑt. ə ʃɔɹt kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən; ə slɪm, plɛzənt-lʊkɪŋ wʊmən ɪn ə sɪmpəl dʒɹɛs; ə stɑki wʊmən huz numɝəs bɹeɪdz mɛnt ʃi wɑz laɪkli fɹəm tæɹɑbən. ðeɪ stʊd wɪð ðə ɡɹup ʌv il wɪmən ɪn ʃɔlz, ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ ə hændfʊl ə meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ. wɛl, ðoʊz il dɪd ɡɪv kɹiɾəns tə ðə kleɪm ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə hæd bɪn sɛn baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Unlike their last meeting, there were Aes Sedai here, three whom he could spot. A short Cairhienin woman; a slim, pleasant-looking woman in a simple dress; a stocky woman whose numerous braids meant she was likely from Tarabon. They stood with the group of Aiel women in shawls, guarded by a handful of Maidens of the Spear. Well, those Aiel did give credence to the claim that Aybara had been sent by the Dragon Reborn.

ɡɑləd ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn kæʒəwəli ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə pəvɪljənz ʌðɝ ɑkjəpəns.

Galad rested his hand casually on the pommel of his sword, looking over the pavilion's other occupants.

ən ðən i fɹoʊz. ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋli bjuɾəfəl wʊmən stʊd bɪhaɪn eɪbə-ɹɑz tʃɛɹ. noʊ, nɑt bjuɾəfəl, ɡɔɹdʒəs. lʌstʃɹəs blæk hɛɹ stʃɹim daʊn pæst əɹ nɛk; ɪt sim tə ʃaɪn. ʃi wɔɹ ə ɹɛd ɡaʊn, θɪn ɪnʌf tə əksɛntʃueɪɾ əɹ fɔɹm ən dipli kʌɾ ɪnʌf tə ɪkspoʊz swɛlɪŋ bʊzəm.

And then he froze. A strikingly beautiful woman stood behind Ayba-ra's chair. No, not beautiful, gorgeous. Lustrous black hair streamed down past her neck; it seemed to shine. She wore a red gown, thin enough to accentuate her form and deeply cut enough to expose swelling bosom.

ən ðoʊz aɪz. soʊ dɑɹk, wɪð lɔŋ bjuɾəfəl læʃɪz. hi simd . .. pʊl təwɔɹd ðɛm. waɪ hædn ðɪs wʊmən kʌm læs taɪm?

And those eyes. So dark, with long beautiful lashes. He seemed . .. pulled toward them. Why hadn't this woman come last time?

"ju əpɪɹ sɝpɹaɪzd," eɪbɑɹə sɛɾ əz i sæt bæk daʊn. hi hæɾ ə ɡɹʌf vɔɪs. "ðə leɪɾi fɝst ɪz hɪɹ ət ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz kəmænd, əz wʌn eɪɛm. dɪdn jə noʊɾəs ðə flæɡ ʌv min əbʌv maɪ fɔɹsɪz?"

"You appear surprised," Aybara said as he sat back down. He had a gruff voice. "The Lady First is here at the Lord Dragon's command, as 1 am. Didn't you notice the flag of Mayene above my forces?"

"aɪ. . ." ɡɑləd snæpt ɪz maʊθ kloʊzd, ɛksəkjuɾɪŋ ə baʊ tə ðə wʊmən. bɹəleɪn sɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ pɹən? ʃi wɑz sɛd tə bi ə mɑɹvələs bjuɾi, bʌt ðoʊz teɪlz dɪɾ əɹ lɪɾəl dʒʌstəs. ɡɑləd tɔɹ ɪz aɪz fɹəm əɹ ən fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə teɪk ðə siɾ ɑpəzəɾ eɪbɑɹə. hi hæd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ɪz foʊ.

"I. . ." Galad snapped his mouth closed, executing a bow to the woman. Berelain sur Paendrag Paeron? She was said to be a marvelous beauty, but those tales did her little justice. Galad tore his eyes from her and forced himself to take the seat opposite Aybara. He had to concentrate on his foe.

ðoʊz ɡoʊldən aɪz wɝ əz ənsɛɾəlɪŋ əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ tə lʊk ɪntu. jɛs, ðɪs mæn kʊdn bi ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ʃæɾoʊzpɔn.

Those golden eyes were as unsettling as he remembered. So strange to look into. Yes, this man couldn't be anything other than Shadowspawn.

waɪ wəd soʊ mɛni fɑloʊ sətʃ ə kɹitʃɝ? waɪ wəd ʃi fɑloʊ sətʃ ə kɹitʃɝ?

Why would so many follow such a creature? Why would she follow such a creature?

"θæŋk jə fəɹ kʌmɪŋ," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "aʊɝ læs miɾɪŋ wɑz heɪsti.

"Thank you for coming," Aybara said. "Our last meeting was hasty.

wɪl də ɪt pɹɑpɝ, ðɪs taɪm. jə ʃəd bi meɪɾ əwɛɹ ðət ðɪs wʊmən bɪsaɪd mi ɪz æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, kwin ʌv ɡildən, blɛsɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, dɪfɛndɝ ʌv ɡæɹənz wɔl." soʊ, ðət steɪtli, dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən wɑz ðə kɝən kwin ʌv ɡildən. ʌv kɔɹs, wɪð ði ənɹɛs hɪɹ leɪtli, ðəɹ wɝ pɹɑbli ə hæf-dʌzən pipəl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn. ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, bʌt kəmplitli oʊvɝʃæɾoʊd baɪ bɹəleɪn.

We'll do it proper, this time. You should be made aware that this woman beside me is Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, Queen of Ghealdan, Blessed of the Light, Defender of Garen's Wall." So, that stately, dark-haired woman was the current Queen of Ghealdan. Of course, with the unrest here lately, there were probably a half-dozen people trying to claim the throne. She was pretty, but completely overshadowed by Berelain.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd təwɔɹɾ ə θɝd wʊmən. "ðɪs ɪz feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ tævbɑɹə, maɪ waɪf ən kʌzən tə ðə kwin ə sɑldɑiə." eɪbɑɹəz waɪf ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɡɑləd wɪð səspɪʃən. jɛs, ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli sɑldəiən, baɪ ðət noʊz. bɔɹnhəld ən baɪɑɝ hædnt noʊn ə hɝ ɹɔɪəl kənɛkʃənz.

Perrin nodded toward a third woman. "This is Faile ni Bashere t'Avbara, my wife and cousin to the Queen of Saldaea." Aybara's wife regarded Galad with suspicion. Yes, she was obviously Saldaean, by that nose. Bornhald and Byar hadn't known of her royal connections.

tu mɑnɑɹks ɪn ðə tɛnt, ən boʊθ bɪhaɪn eɪbɑɹə. ɡɑləd ɹoʊz fɹəm ɪz siɾ ən ɡeɪv ə baʊ tə æliændɝ tə mætʃ ðə wʌn hid ɡɪvən bɹəleɪn. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti."

Two monarchs in the tent, and both behind Aybara. Galad rose from his seat and gave a bow to Alliandre to match the one he'd given Berelain. "Your Majesty."

"jɔɹ vɛɹi pəlaɪt, lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "æn ðoʊz wɝ ɛləɡən baʊz.

"You're very polite, Lord Captain Commander," Berelain said. "And those were elegant bows.

tɛl mi, wɛɹ dɪd jə ɹəsiv sətʃ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ?"

Tell me, where did you receive such training?"

hɝ vɔɪs wɑz laɪk mjuzɪk. "ɪn ðə kɔɹɾ ʌv ændɝ, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪm ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd, stɛpsʌn ə ðə dɪpɑɹɾəd kwin mɔɹɡeɪs ən hæf-bɹʌðɝ ʌv ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, ðə ɹaɪtfəl kwin."

Her voice was like music. "In the court of Andor, my Lady. I am Galad Damodred, stepson of the departed Queen Morgase and half-brother of Elayne Trakand, the rightful Queen."

"ɑ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "əbaʊt taɪm aɪ pʊɾ ə neɪm tə ju. wɪʃ jud sɛd ðət læs taɪm."

"Ah," Perrin said. "About time I put a name to you. Wish you'd said that last time."

bɹəleɪn stɛɹɾ ɪndə hɪz aɪz, ən ʃi smaɪld, lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə stɛp fɔɹwɝd. ʃi kɑt hɝsɛlf, haʊɛvɝ. "ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd. jɛs, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn jəɹ feɪs. haʊ ɪz jəɹ sɪstɝ?"

Berelain stared into his eyes, and she smiled, looking as if she wanted to step forward. She caught herself, however. "Galad Damodred. Yes, I thought I recognized something in your face. How is your sister?"

"aɪ hoʊp ʃiz wɛl," ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ hæv nɑt sin əɹ ɪn səm taɪm."

"I hope she is well," Galad said. "I have not seen her in some time."

"ɪleɪnz faɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "læst aɪ hɝd - wɪtʃ wɑz oʊnli ə fju deɪz bæk - ʃid sɪkjʊɹɾ əɹ kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn. aɪ wʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ʃiz lʊkɪŋ tə mɛɹi ɹænd baɪ naʊ. ɪf ʃi kən pʊl ɪm əweɪ fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ ɹɛlm hiz kɑŋkɝɪŋ."

"Elayne's fine," Perrin said gruffly. "Last I heard - which was only a few days back - she'd secured her claim to the throne. I wouldn't be surprised if she's looking to marry Rand by now. If she can pull him away from whatever realm he's conquering."

bɪhaɪnd ɡɑləd, baɪɑɝ hɪst sɔfli. hæɾ eɪbɑɹə ɪntɛndəɾ ɪnsəl baɪ ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp bɪtwin ɪleɪn ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɡɑləd nu hɪz sɪstɝ ɔl tu wɛl. ʃi wɑz ɪmpʌlsɪv, ən ʃi hæd ʃoʊn ən ənsimli fæsəneɪʃən wɪð jʌŋ ælθɹ.

Behind Galad, Byar hissed softly. Had Aybara intended insult by indicating a relationship between Elayne and the Dragon Reborn? Unfortunately, Galad knew his sister all too well. She was impulsive, and she had shown an unseemly fascination with young al'Thor.

maɪ sɪstɝ meɪ də əz ʃi wɪʃɪz," ɡɑləd sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ izəli hi kənteɪn ɪz ənɔɪəns ət boʊθ əɹ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. "wi ɑɹ hɪɹ tə dɪskʌs ju, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, ən jəɹ ɑɹmi."

My sister may do as she wishes," Galad said, surprised at how easily he contained his annoyance at both her and the Dragon Reborn. "We are here to discuss you, Perrin Aybara, and your army."

eɪbɑɹə lin fɔɹwɝd, leɪɪŋ tu hænz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "wi boʊθ noʊ ðɪs ɪzən əbaʊt maɪ ɑɹmi."

Aybara leaned forward, laying two hands on the table. "We both know this isn't about my army."

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪɾ əbaʊt, ðɛn?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

"What is it about, then?" Galad asked.

eɪbɑɹə mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz wɪð ðoʊz ənnætʃɹəl aɪz ə hɪz. "ɪts əbaʊɾ ə pɛɹ ə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ aɪ kɪl tu jɪɹz bæk. naʊ ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ tɝn ɝaʊnd, ɪt simz ðət ðəɹ ɪz ə ɡɹup ə jə snæpɪŋ ət maɪ hilz."
