Aybara met his gaze with those unnatural eyes of his. "It's about a pair of Children of the Light I killed two years back. Now every time I turn around, it seems that there is a group of you snapping at my heels."

ɪt wɑzn ɔfən ðəɾ ə mɝɾɝɝ wɑz soʊ oʊpən əbaʊt wʌɾ i hæd dʌn. ɡɑləd hɝd ðə ɹæsp ʌv ə sɔɹd biɪŋ dʒɹɔn bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən ɹeɪzd ə hænd. "tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld! jəl kəntʃɹoʊl jɝsɛlf!"

It wasn't often that a murderer was so open about what he had done. Galad heard the rasp of a sword being drawn behind him, and raised a hand. "Child Bornhald! You will control yourself!"

"tu tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, ʃæɾoʊzpɔn?" bɔɹnhəl spæt. "ænd wʌɾ ə maɪ fɑðɝ?"

"Two Children of the Light, Shadowspawn?" Bornhald spat. "And what of my father?"

"aɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz dɛθ, bɔɹnhəld," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "dʒɛəfɹæm wɑz kɪl baɪ ðə sintʃæn, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. fəɹ ə waɪtkloʊk, hi sim laɪk ə ɹizənəbəl mæn, ðoʊ hi wɑz plænɪŋ tə hæŋ mi."

"I had nothing to do with his death, Bornhald," Aybara said. "Geofram was killed by the Seanchan, unfortunately. For a Whitecloak, he seemed like a reasonable man, though he was planning to hang me."

"hi wɑz tə hæŋ jə fəɹ ðə mɝɾɝz jə dʒʌs kənfɛs tə," ɡɑləd sɛd kɑmli, ʃuɾɪŋ ə ɡlæns ət bɔɹnhəld. ðə mæn snæpt ɪz sɔɹd bæk ɪn ɪts ʃiθ, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz ɹɛd.

"He was to hang you for the murders you just confessed to," Galad said calmly, shooting a glance at Bornhald. The man snapped his sword back in its sheath, but his face was red.

"ðeɪ wɝn mɝɾɝz," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "ðeɪ ətæk mi. aɪ fɔt bæk."

"They weren't murders," Aybara said. "They attacked me. I fought back."

"ðæɾ ɪz nɑt wʌɾ aɪ hæv hɝd," ɡɑləd sɛd. wʌt ɡeɪm wɑz ðɪs mæn pleɪɪŋ? "aɪ hæv swɔɹn tɛstəmoʊni ðət jə wɝ haɪɾɪŋ ʌndɝniθ ə klft ɪn ðə ɹɑk. wən ðə mɛn æsk jə tə kʌm aʊt, jə dʒʌmpt aʊt skɹimɪŋ ən ətækt əm wɪθaʊt pɹɑvəkeɪʃən."

"That is not what I have heard," Galad said. What game was this man playing? "I have sworn testimony that you were hiding underneath a cleft in the rock. When the men asked you to come out, you jumped out screaming and attacked them without provocation."

"oʊ, ðəɹ wɑz pɹɑvəkeɪʃən," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "jɔɹ waɪtkloʊks kɪld ə fɹɛn ə maɪn."

"Oh, there was provocation," Aybara said. "Your Whitecloaks killed a friend of mine."

"ðə wʊmən u wɑz wɪð ju?" ɡɑləɾ æskt. "fɹʌm wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ, ʃi ɪskeɪp seɪfli." hid bɪn ʃɑkt wən bɔɹnhəl hæd mɛnʃən ðət neɪm. ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. ənʌðɝ wʊmən u sim tə pɹəfɝ deɪnʒɝəs kʌmpəni.

"The woman who was with you?" Galad asked. "From what I hear, she escaped safely." He'd been shocked when Bornhald had mentioned that name. Egwene al'Vere. Another woman who seemed to prefer dangerous company.

"nɑt hɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ə fɹɛnd neɪm hɑpɝ. ən æftɝ hɪm, ə kəmpænjən ə hɪz. ðeɪ wɝ wʊlvz."

"Not her," Perrin said. "A friend named Hopper. And after him, a companion of his. They were wolves."

ðə mæn wɑz kəndɛmɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɝðɝ! "ju meɪk fɹɛnz ʌv wʊlvz, noʊn tə bi kɹitʃɝz ə ðə ʃædoʊ?"

The man was condemning himself further! "You make friends of wolves, known to be creatures of the Shadow?"

"wʊlvz ɑɹən ə ðə ʃædoʊ," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "ðeɪ heɪt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni mæn aɪv noʊn."

"Wolves aren't of the Shadow," Aybara said. "They hate Shadowspawn as much as any man I've known."

"æn haʊ dʒju noʊ ðɪs?"

"And how do you know this?"

eɪbɑɹə sɛd nʌθɪŋ fɝðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðɛɹ. baɪɑɝ sɛd ðɪs mæn simd eɪbəl tə kəmænd wʊlvz, ɹʌn wɪð ðɛm, laɪk ə wʊlf hɪmsɛlf. ðət tɛstəmoʊni wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt hæd pɝsweɪɾəd ɡɑləd ðət bæɾəl wɑz ði oʊnli ɹikɔɹs. ɪt sim ðət baɪɑɝz wɝdz hæd nɑt bɪn ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃən.

Aybara said nothing further. There was more there. Byar said this man seemed able to command wolves, run with them, like a wolf himself. That testimony was part of what had persuaded Galad that battle was the only recourse. It seemed that Byar's words had not been exaggeration.

bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid, jɛt, tə dwɛl ɑn ðæt. eɪbɑɹə hæɾ ədmɪɾəd tə mɝɾɝ. "aɪ doʊn æksɛp ðə kɪlɪŋ ʌv wʊlvz əz sʌmθɪŋ tə ɪɡzɑnɝeɪt ju," ɡɑləd sɛd. "mɛni hʌntɝz sleɪ wʊlvz u ətæk ðɛɹ flɑks əɹ θɹɛɾən ðɛɹ lɪvz. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən dɪd nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. jəɹ ətæk ɑn ðɛm, ðɛɹfɔɹ, wɑz ʌnpɹəvoʊk mɝɾɝ."

But there was no need, yet, to dwell on that. Aybara had admitted to murder. "I don't accept the killing of wolves as something to exonerate you," Galad said. "Many hunters slay wolves who attack their flocks or threaten their lives. The Children did nothing wrong. Your attack on them, therefore, was unprovoked murder."

"ðɛɹ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ðæt," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ daʊɾ əl kənvɪns jə ʌv ðæt."

"There was far more to it than that," Aybara said. "But I doubt I'll convince you of that."

"aɪ kænɑt bi kənvɪnst ə sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪzən tʃɹu," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"I cannot be convinced of something that isn't true," Galad said.

"æn jə woʊn liv mi əloʊn, iðɝ," eɪbɑɹə sɛd.

"And you won't leave me alone, either," Aybara said.

"wi ɑɹ əɾ ən ɪmpæs, ðɛn," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ju hæv kənfɛs tə kɹaɪmz ðəɾ aɪ, əz ə sɝvən ə dʒʌstəs, mʌst si ɹaɪɾɪd. aɪ kænɑt wɔk əweɪ. jə si waɪ aɪ fɛl fɝðɝ pɑɹli wɑz jusləs?"

"We are at an impasse, then," Galad said. "You have confessed to crimes that I, as a servant of justice, must see righted. I cannot walk away. You see why I felt further parley was useless?"

"wʌɾ ɪf aɪ wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə stæn tʃɹaɪəl?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What if I were willing to stand trial?" Perrin asked.

eɪbɑɹəz boʊld-noʊzd waɪf ɹɛstəɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi ɹitʃt ʌp ən leɪɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪt, bʌt dɪd nɑt tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ɡɑləd.

Aybara's bold-nosed wife rested a hand on his shoulder. He reached up and laid his hand on it, but did not turn away from Galad.

"ɪf jəl kʌm ən æksɛpt pʌnɪʃmən fɹəm əs fəɹ wʌt juv dʌn . . " ɡɑləd sɛd. ɪt wəd min ɛksəkjuʃən. ʃʊɹli ðə kɹitʃɝ wʊdnt ɡɪv hɪmsɛlf ʌp.

"If you will come and accept punishment from us for what you've done . . " Galad said. It would mean execution. Surely the creature wouldn't give himself up.

ət ðə bæk ə ðə pəvɪljən, ə ɡɹup ə sɝvəns hæɾ ɝaɪvd ən wɝ pɹipɛɹɪŋ ti. ti. əɾ ə wɔɹ pɑɹli. ɑbviəsli eɪbɑɹə hæd lɪɾəl ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ðɪs kaɪndə θɪŋ.

At the back of the pavilion, a group of servants had arrived and were preparing tea. Tea. At a war parley. Obviously Aybara had little experience with this kind of thing.

"nɑt pʌnɪʃmənt," eɪbɑɹə sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ə tʃɹaɪəl. ɪf aɪm pɹuvən ɪnəsənt, aɪ ɡoʊ fɹi ən jə - ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ - ɪnstʃɹʌk jəɹ mɛn tə stɑp haʊndɪŋ mi. ɪspɛʃli bɔɹnhəld ən ðət wʌn bɪhaɪn jə hu ɡɹaʊlz laɪk ə pʌp siɪŋ ɪz fɝs lɛpɝd."

"Not punishment," Aybara said sharply. "A trial. If I am proven innocent, I go free and you - the Lord Captain Commander - instruct your men to stop hounding me. Especially Bornhald and that one behind you who growls like a pup seeing his first leopard."

"æn ɪf jə ɑɹ pɹuvən ɡɪlti?"

"And if you are proven guilty?"

"ðæt dɪpɛnz."

"That depends."

"doʊn lɪsən tə hɪm, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ!" baɪɑɝ sɛd. "hi pɹɑməs tə ɡɪv hɪmsɛlf tə əs wʌns bɪfɔɹ, ðən bɪtʃɹeɪɾ ɪz wɝd!"

"Don't listen to him, my Lord Captain Commander!" Byar said. "He promised to give himself to us once before, then betrayed his word!"

"aɪ dɪd nɑt!" eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "ju dɪd nɑt fʊlfɪl jəɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən!"

"I did not!" Aybara said. "You did not fulfill your part of the bargain!"

ɡɑləd slæp ðə teɪbəl. "ðɪs ɪz jusləs. ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ tʃɹaɪəl." "waɪ nɑt?" eɪbɑɹə dɪmændəd.

Galad slapped the table. "This is useless. There will be no trial." "Why not?" Aybara demanded.

"ju tɔk ə dʒʌstəs, bʌt woʊn ɔfɝ mi ə tʃɹaɪəl?"

"You talk of justice, but won't offer me a trial?"

"æn u wəd dʒʌdʒ ɪt?" ɡɑləɾ æskt. "wʊd jə tʃɹʌs mi tə də soʊ?" ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ æliændɝ kæn. ʃiz ə kwin."

"And who would judge it?" Galad asked. "Would you trust me to do so?" Of course not," Perrin said. "But Alliandre can. She's a queen."

"æn jəɹ kəmpænjən," ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ min əɹ noʊ ɪnsəlt, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ʃi wəɾ əkwɪt jə wɪθaʊt hɪɹɪŋ ɛvəɾəns. ivən ðə leɪɾi fɝst wəd nɑt bi æɾəkwət - ðoʊ aɪ wʊd, ʌv kɔɹs, tʃɹʌst əɹ wɝd, aɪ fɪɹ ðət maɪ mɛn wəd nɑt."

"And your companion," Galad said. "I mean her no insult, but I fear she would acquit you without hearing evidence. Even the Lady First would not be adequate - though I would, of course, trust her word, I fear that my men would not."

laɪt, bʌt ðət wʊmən wɑz bjuɾəfəl! hi ɡlænst əɾ əɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən faʊn əɹ blʌʃɪŋ əz ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɪm. ɪt wɑz feɪnt, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ i sɔ ɪt. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf blʌʃɪŋ əz wɛl.

Light, but that woman was beautiful! He glanced at her for a moment, and found her blushing as she regarded him. It was faint, but he was sure he saw it. He found himself blushing as well.

"ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðɛn," eɪbɑɹə sɛd.

"The Aes Sedai, then," Aybara said.

ɡɑləd tɔɹ ɪz aɪz əweɪ fɹəm bɹəleɪn ən lʊkt əɾ eɪbɑɹə, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə flæt stɛɹ. "ɪf jə θɪŋk ðəɾ ə dʒʌdʒmən baɪ wʌn fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd sæɾəsfaɪ maɪ mɛn, jə noʊ lɪɾəl ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪ pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

Galad tore his eyes away from Berelain and looked at Aybara, giving him a flat stare. "If you think that a judgment by one from the White Tower would satisfy my men, you know little of the Children of the Ligh Perrin Aybara."

eɪbɑɹəz aɪz ɡɹu hɑɹd. jɛs, hi nu ðæt. ɪt wɑz tu bæd. ə tʃɹaɪəl wʊɾə bɪn ə taɪɾi ɛn tə ðɪs. ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən əpɹoʊtʃt ðə teɪbəl wɪð tu kʌps ə ti, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid. ðɪs sɛkən pɑɹli wɑz oʊvɝ.

Aybara's eyes grew hard. Yes, he knew that. It was too bad. A trial would have been a tidy end to this. A serving woman approached the table with two cups of tea, but there was no need. This second parley was over.

"jɔɹ ɹaɪt, ðɛn," eɪbɑɹə sɛd, lʊkɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. "ðɪs miɾɪŋ wɑz pɔɪnləs."

"You're right, then," Aybara said, looking frustrated. "This meeting was pointless."

"noʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd, stilɪŋ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ət bɹəleɪn. "nɑt pɔɪnləs fəɹ mi." hi nu mɔɹ ʌv eɪbɑɹəz stʃɹɛŋkθ; ðət wəd hɛlp ɪm ɪn bæɾəl. bɪɑn ðæt, ɪt hæd bɪn ɹaɪt tə dɪleɪ faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm tə meɪk sɝɾən ɪt wɑz niɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl plɛnti ʌv laɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ fəɹ ðə faɪɾɪŋ tə pɹəsid.

"No," Galad said, stealing another glance at Berelain. "Not pointless for me." He knew more of Aybara's strength; that would help him in battle. Beyond that, it had been right to delay fighting for a short time to make certain it was needed. There was still plenty of light in the day for the fighting to proceed.

bʌt . . . wʌɾ ə ðət wʊmən . . . ðə leɪɾi fɝst? hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə lʊk əweɪ. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəlt.

But . . . what of that woman . . . the Lady First? He forced himself to look away. It was difficult.

ɡɑləd stʊd, ən baʊd tə æliændɝ, ðən tə bɹəleɪn. hi muv tə liv.

Galad stood, and bowed to Alliandre, then to Berelain. He moved to leave.

ðən i hɝɾ ə ɡæsp. ɑdli, ɪt keɪm fɹəm ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən u hæd bɹɔt ðə ti. ɡɑləd ɡlænst ət hɝ.

Then he heard a gasp. Oddly, it came from the serving woman who had brought the tea. Galad glanced at her.

ɪt wɑz mɔɹɡeɪs.

It was Morgase.

ɡɑləd fɹoʊz, kəmplitli stɪl. hid bɪn tʃɹeɪn baɪ sɔɹdmæstɝ æftɝ sɔɹdmæstɝ nɛvɝ tə lɛɾ ɪz sɝpɹaɪz oʊvɝwɛlm hɪm, bʌɾ ət ðət moʊmənt, ðɛɹ kɛɹfəl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɑz fəɹ nɔt. ðət wɑz ɪz stɛpmʌðɝ. ðət ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ i hæd tʌɡd əz ə tʃaɪld. ðət feɪs, soʊ bjuɾəfəl ən stʃɹɔŋ. ðoʊz aɪz. ðoʊz wɝ əɹ aɪz.

Galad froze, completely still. He'd been trained by swordmaster after swordmaster never to let his surprise overwhelm him, but at that moment, their careful training was for naught. That was his stepmother. That red-gold hair he had tugged as a child. That face, so beautiful and strong. Those eyes. Those were her eyes.

ə ɡoʊst? hi hæd hɝd ðə stɔɹiz. mænəfɛsteɪʃənz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ivəl ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə dɛd tə laɪf.

A ghost? He had heard the stories. Manifestations of the Dark One's evil returning the dead to life.

bʌt noʊbɑdi ɛls ɪn ðə pəvɪljən simd ənizi, ən ðɪs wʊmən wɑz tu ɹil. hɛzɪɾəntli, ɡɑləd ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʌtʃt ði æpɝɪʃən ɑn ðə tʃik. ðə skɪn wɑz wɔɹm.

But nobody else in the pavilion seemed uneasy, and this woman was too real. Hesitantly, Galad reached out and touched the apparition on the cheek. The skin was warm.

"ɡɑləd?" ʃi sɛd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ? haʊ - "

"Galad?" she said. "What are you doing here? How - "

ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz i sizd əɹ ɪn ən ɛmbɹeɪs, kɑzɪŋ ðoʊz ɝaʊn ɪm ɑn boʊθ saɪdz tə dʒʌmp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ʃi dʒʌmpt, tu. ʃi lɪvd! haʊ?

She cut off as he seized her in an embrace, causing those around him on both sides to jump in surprise. She jumped, too. She lived! How?

aɪ kɪl vɑldə, ɡɑləd θɔɾ ɪmiɾiətli. kɪld ɪm fəɹ ðə dɛθ ə maɪ mʌðɝ. hu ɪz nɑt dɛd. aɪ hæv dʌn ivəl.

I killed Valda, Galad thought immediately. Killed him for the death of my mother. Who is not dead. I have done evil.

noʊ. vɑldə hæd dɪzɝv tə daɪ fəɹ ði əsɔlt ɑn mɔɹɡeɪs. əɹ wɑz ðət pɑɹt tʃɹu? hi hæd spoʊkən tə tʃɪlʒɹən ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz, bʌt ðeɪɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪn ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz dɛd.

No. Valda had deserved to die for the assault on Morgase. Or was that part true? He had spoken to Children sure that it was, but they'd also been sure she was dead.

hi wəd sɔɹt ðəɾ aʊt leɪɾɝ. ɹaɪt naʊ, hi niɾəd tə stɑp ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz mɛn. hi ɹilist ɪz stɛpmʌðɝ, bʌt ʃi kɛp hoʊld ə hɪz ɑɹm. ʃi lʊk deɪzd. hi hæd ɹɛɹli sin əɹ ðət weɪ.

He would sort that out later. Right now, he needed to stop embarrassing himself in front of his men. He released his stepmother, but she kept hold of his arm. She looked dazed. He had rarely seen her that way.

pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə hæd stʊɾ ʌp ən wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əm wɪð ə fɹaʊn. "ju noʊ meɪaɪɡdɪn?"

Perrin Aybara had stood up and was watching them with a frown. "You know Maighdin?"

"meɪaɪɡdɪn?" ɡɑləɾ æskt. ʃi wɔɹ ə sɪmpəl dʒɹɛs ən noʊ dʒuəlɹi. wɑz ʃi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪɾ əz ə sɝvənt? "eɪbɑɹə, ðɪs ɪz mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm, pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə pipəl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. ʃiz jəɹ kwinəl"

"Maighdin?" Galad asked. She wore a simple dress and no jewelry. Was she trying to hide as a servant? "Aybara, this is Morgase Trakand, Defender of the Realm, Protector of the People, High Seat of House Trakand. She is your queenl"

ðət bɹɔɾ ə stɪlnəs tə ðə pəvɪljən. eɪbɑɹə skɹætʃt əɾ ɪz bɪɹd θɔtfəli. hɪz waɪf wɑtʃt mɔɹɡeɪs wɪð aɪz waɪd, iðɝ ʃɑkt əɹ æŋɡɹi.

That brought a stillness to the pavilion. Aybara scratched at his beard thoughtfully. His wife watched Morgase with eyes wide, either shocked or angry.

"meɪaɪɡdɪn," eɪbɑɹə sɛd, "ɪz ðɪs tʃɹu?"

"Maighdin," Aybara said, "is this true?"

ʃi lɪftəɾ əɹ tʃɪn, stɛɹɪŋ eɪbɑɹə ɪn ði aɪz. haʊ kəd ðeɪ nɑt si ðə kwin ɪn hɝ?

She lifted her chin, staring Aybara in the eyes. How could they not see the Queen in her?

"aɪ æm mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd," ʃi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv ɹɪnaʊns maɪ θɹoʊn ɪn feɪvɝ ʌv ɪleɪn. bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪt, əl nɛvɝ əɡɛn kleɪm ðə kɹaʊn."

"I am Morgase Trakand," she said. "But I have renounced my throne in favor of Elayne. Before the Light, I will never again claim the crown."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. jɛs. ʃi mʌst əv fɪɹd ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə wəd juz əɹ əɡɛnst ændɝ. "aɪm teɪkɪŋ jə bæk tə maɪ kæmp, mʌðɝ," ɡɑləd sɛd, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ eɪbɑɹə. "ðɛn wi kən dɪskʌs ðə weɪ jə wɝ tʃɹiɾəd baɪ ðɪs mæn."

Galad nodded. Yes. She must have feared that Aybara would use her against Andor. "I'm taking you back to my camp, Mother," Galad said, still watching Aybara. "Then we can discuss the way you were treated by this man."

ʃi tɝn lɛvəl aɪz ɑn ɡɑləd. "æn ɔɹɾɝ, ɡɑləd? hæv aɪ noʊ seɪ ɪn ðə mæɾɝ?"

She turned level eyes on Galad. "An order, Galad? Have I no say in the matter?"

hi fɹaʊnd, linɪŋ ɪn ən spikɪŋ ɪn ə wɪspɝ. "dʌz i hæv ʌðɝz kæptɪv? wʌt lɛvɝɪdʒ dʌz i hæv oʊvɝ ju?"

He frowned, leaning in and speaking in a whisper. "Does he have others captive? What leverage does he have over you?"

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən ɹɪplaɪd sɔfli, "ðɪs mæn ɪz nɑt wʌt jə θɪŋk i ɪz, ɡɑləd. hiz ɹʌf- kʌt, ən aɪ sɝɾənli doʊn laɪk wʌt hiz duɪŋ tə ændɝ, bʌt hiz noʊ fɹɛn ə ðə ʃædoʊ. aɪ hæv mɔɹ tə fɪɹ fɹəm jəɹ . . . əsoʊsiɪts ðən fɹəm pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

She shook her head and replied softly, "This man is not what you think he is, Galad. He's rough- cut, and I certainly don't like what he's doing to Andor, but he is no friend of the Shadow. I have more to fear from your . . . associates than from Perrin Aybara."

jɛs, ʃi dɪɾ əv ɹizən tə dɪstʃɹʌs ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ɡʊd ɹizən. "wɪl jə kʌm wɪð mi, maɪ leɪɾi? aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðət jə meɪ liv ən ɹɪtɝn tə eɪbɑɹəz kæmp əɾ ɛni taɪm. wʌtɛvɝ jə sʌfɝd fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn ðə pæst, jəl bi seɪf naʊ. aɪ vaʊ ðɪs."

Yes, she did have reason to distrust the Children. Good reason. "Will you come with me, my Lady? I promise you that you may leave and return to Aybara's camp at any time. Whatever you suffered from the Children in the past, you will be safe now. I vow this."

mɔɹɡeɪs ɡeɪv ɪm ə nɑd. "dəmədʒɹd," eɪbɑɹə sɛd, "weɪɾ ə moʊmənt."

Morgase gave him a nod. "Damodred," Aybara said, "wait a moment."

ɡɑləd tɝnd, leɪɪŋ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd pɑməl əɡɛn. nɑɾ əz ə θɹɛt, bʌɾ ə ɹimaɪndɝ. mɛni ʌv ðoʊz ɪn ðə pəvɪljən hæd bɪɡʌn tə wɪspɝ. "jɛs?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

Galad turned, laying his hand on his sword pommel again. Not as a threat, but a reminder. Many of those in the pavilion had begun to whisper. "Yes?" Galad asked.

"ju wɑntəɾ ə dʒʌdʒ," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "wʊd jə æksɛp jəɹ mʌðɝ ɪn ðət pəzɪʃən?"

"You wanted a judge," Aybara said. "Would you accept your mother in that position?"

ɡɑləd dɪdn hɛzəteɪt. ʌv kɔɹs; ʃid bɪn ə kwin sɪns əɹ eɪtinθ neɪmdeɪ, ən i hæd sin əɹ sɪɾ ɪn dʒʌdʒmənt. ʃi wɑz fɛɹ. hɑɹʃ, bʌt fɛɹ.

Galad didn't hesitate. Of course; she'd been a queen since her eighteenth nameday, and he had seen her sit in judgment. She was fair. Harsh, but fair.

bʌt wəd ði ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən æksɛp hɝ? ʃid bɪn tʃɹeɪn baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪd si hɝ əz wʌn ə ðɛm. ə pɹɑbləm. bʌɾ ɪf ɪt ɡeɪv ə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðɪs, pɝhæps i kəd meɪk əm si ðə tʃɹuθ.

But would the other Children accept her? She'd been trained by the Aes Sedai. They'd see her as one of them. A problem. But if it gave a way out of this, perhaps he could make them see the truth.

"aɪ wʊd," ɡɑləd sɛd. "æn ɪf aɪ vaʊtʃt fəɹ hɝ, maɪ mɛn wəɾ əz wɛl."

"I would," Galad said. "And if I vouched for her, my men would as well."

"wɛl," eɪbɑɹə sɛd, "aɪɾ æksɛp hɝ, tu."

"Well," Aybara said, "I'd accept her, too."

boʊθ mɛn tɝn tə mɔɹɡeɪs. ʃi stʊɾ ɪn əɹ sɪmpəl jɛloʊ dʒɹɛs, lʊkɪŋ mɔɹ ə kwin baɪ ðə moʊmənt. "pɛɹɪn," ʃi sɛd, "ɪf aɪ sɪɾ ɪn dʒʌdʒmənt, əl nɑt tɛmpɝ maɪ dɪsɪʒənz. jə tʊk mi ɪn wən wi niɾəd ʃɛltɝ, ən fəɹ ðəɾ aɪm əpɹiʃieɪɾɪv. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ dɪsaɪd ðət juv kəmɪɾəd mɝɾɝ, əl nɑt hoʊl bæk maɪ dɪsɪʒən."

Both men turned to Morgase. She stood in her simple yellow dress, looking more a queen by the moment. "Perrin," she said, "if I sit in judgment, I will not temper my decisions. You took me in when we needed shelter, and for that I am appreciative. But if I decide that you have committed murder, I will not hold back my decision."

"ðæt wɪl du," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. hi sim sənsɪɹ.

"That will do," Aybara said. He seemed sincere.

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," baɪɑɝ sɛd sɔfli ɪn ɡɑləɾ ɛs ɪɹ, saʊndɪŋ fɝvənt. "aɪ fɪɹ ðɪs wəd bi ə fɑɹs! hiz nɑt sɛɾ i wəd səbmɪt tə pʌnɪʃmənt."

"My Lord Captain Commander," Byar said softly in Galad s ear, sounding fervent. "I fear this would be a farce! He's not said he would submit to punishment."

"noʊ, aɪ hæv nɑt," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. haʊ hæɾ i hɝd ðoʊz wɪspɝz? "ɪt wəd bi minɪŋləs. jə θɪŋk mi ə dɑɹkfɹɛn ən ə mɝɾɝɝ. jə wʊdn æksɛp maɪ wɝɾ ɑn teɪkɪŋ pʌnɪʃmənt, nɑɾ ənlɛs aɪ wɑz ɪn jəɹ kʌstəɾi. wɪtʃ aɪ woʊn əlaʊ."

"No, I have not," Aybara said. How had he heard those whispers? "It would be meaningless. You think me a Darkfriend and a murderer. You wouldn't accept my word on taking punishment, not unless I was in your custody. Which I won't allow."

"si?" baɪɑɝ sɛd, mɔɹ laʊdli. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɔɪnt?"

"See?" Byar said, more loudly. "What is the point?"

ɡɑləd mɛɾ eɪbɑɹəz ɡoʊldən aɪz əɡɛn. "ɪt wɪl ɡɪv əs ə tʃɹaɪəl," hi sɛd, ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ sɝɾən.

Galad met Aybara's golden eyes again. "It will give us a trial," he said, growing more certain.

"æn liɡəl dʒʌstəfəkeɪʃən. aɪm bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə si, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. wi mʌs pɹuv əɹ kleɪmz, ʌðɝwaɪz wəɹ noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən æsu-nɑwə."

"And legal justification. I'm beginning to see, Child Byar. We must prove our claims, otherwise we are no better than Asu-nawa."

"bʌt ðə tʃɹaɪəl wɪl nɑt bi fɛɹ!"

"But the trial will not be fair!"

ɡɑləd tɝn tə ðə tɔl soʊlʒɝ. "ɑɹ jə kwɛstʃənɪŋ maɪ mʌðɝz ɪmpɑɹʃiælɪɾi?"

Galad turned to the tall soldier. "Are you questioning my mother's impartiality?"

ðə ɡɔn mæn fɹoʊz, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ."

The gaunt man froze, then shook his head. "No, my Lord Captain Commander."

ɡɑləd tɝn bæk tə eɪbɑɹə. "aɪ æsk kwin æliændɝ tə ɡɹæn ðət ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl bi liɡəli baɪndɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɹɛlm."

Galad turned back to Aybara. "I ask Queen Alliandre to grant that this trial be legally binding in her realm."

"ɪf lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə ɹɪkwɛsts ɪt, aɪ wɪl." ʃi saʊndəɾ ənkʌmftəɹbəl.

"If Lord Aybara requests it, I will." She sounded uncomfortable.

"aɪ də ɹɪkwɛst ɪt, æliændɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ oʊnli ɪf dəmədʒɹɾ əɡɹiz tə ɹilis ɔl ə maɪ pipəl ðət hiz hoʊldɪŋ. kip ðə səplaɪz, bʌt lɛt ðə pipəl ɡoʊ, əz jə pɹɑməs mi jə wəd bɪfɔɹ."

"I do request it, Alliandre," Perrin said. "But only if Damodred agrees to release all of my people that he's holding. Keep the supplies, but let the people go, as you promised me you would before."

"vɛɹi wɛl," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ɪt wɪl hæpən wʌns ðə tʃɹaɪəl bɪɡɪnz. aɪ pɹɑməs ɪt. wən wɪl wi mit?"

"Very well," Galad said. "It will happen once the trial begins. I promise it. When will we meet?"

"ɡɪv mi ə fju deɪz tə pɹipɛɹ."

"Give me a few days to prepare."

"ɪn θɹi deɪz, ðɛn," ɡɑləd sɛd. "wi hoʊl ðə tʃɹaɪəl hɪɹ, ɪn ðɪs pəvəl- aɪən, ɪn ðɪs pleɪs."

"In three days, then," Galad said. "We hold the trial here, in this pavil- ion, in this place."

"bɹɪŋ jəɹ wɪtnəsəz," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "aɪl bi hɪɹ.

"Bring your witnesses," Aybara said. "I'll be here.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən


CHAPTER 27

eɪ kɔl tə stænd


A Call to Stand

aɪm nɑɾ əpoʊz tə kwɛstʃənɪŋ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ɛɡwin ɹɛd fɹəm ðə lɛɾɝ əz ʃi sæɾ ɪn əɹ stʌɾi. ɪndid, ðə mɔɹ æbsəluɾ ə mænz paʊɝ bɪkʌmz, ðə mɔɹ nɛsəsɛɹi kwɛstʃənɪŋ bɪkʌmz.

I am not opposed to questioning the Lord Dragon, Egwene read from the letter as she sat in her study. Indeed, the more absolute a man's power becomes, the more necessary questioning becomes.

haʊɛvɝ, noʊ ðəɾ aɪm nɑɾ ə mæn u ɡɪvz ɪz lɔɪəlti izəli, ən aɪ eɪtʃ ævənu ɡɪvən maɪ lɔɪəlti tə hɪm.

However, know that I am not a man who gives his loyalty easily, and I h ave given my loyalty to him.

nɑt kəz ə ðə θɹoʊn i pɹəvaɪɾəd mi, bʌt kəz ʌv wʌt hiz dʌn fəɹ tɛɹ. jɛs, hi ɡɹoʊz mɔɹ ɪɹæɾɪk baɪ ðə deɪ. wʌɾ ɛls ɑɹ wi tə ɪkspɛk fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? hɪl bɹeɪk ðə wɝld. wi nu ðɪs wən wi ɡeɪv ɪm əɹ əlidʒəns, mʌtʃ əz ə seɪlɝ mʌst səmtaɪmz ɡɪv ɪz lɔɪəlti tə ðə kæptən u stɪɹz ɪz ʃɪp stʃɹeɪt fəɹ ðə stʃɹænd. wən ən ənnəvəɡəbəl tɛmpəst ɹaɪzəz bɪhaɪnd, ðə stʃɹæn ɪz ði oʊnli ɑpʃən. stɪl, jəɹ wɝdz bɹɪŋ mi kənsɝn. ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə ðə silz ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ wi ʃəɾ ʌndɝteɪk wɪθaʊt kɛɹfəl dɪskʌʃən. ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən tʃɑɹdʒ mi wɪð ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪm ən ɑɹmi, ən aɪ hæv dʌn soʊ. ɪf jə pɹəvaɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪz juv pɹɑməst, əl bɹɪŋ səm tʃɹups tə ðɪs miɾɪŋ pleɪs, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə lɔɪəl haɪ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz. bi wɔɹnd, haʊɛvɝ, ðət ðə sintʃæn pɹɛzəns tə maɪ wɛs kəntɪnjuz tə weɪ hɛvəli əpɑn maɪ maɪnd. ðə bʌlk ə maɪ ɑɹmiz mʌst ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd.

Not because of the throne he provided me, but because of what he has done for Tear. Yes, he grows more erratic by the day. What else are we to expect from the Dragon Reborn? He will break the world. We knew this when we gave him our allegiance, much as a sailor must sometimes give his loyalty to the captain who steers his ship straight for the strand. When an unnavigable tempest rises behind, the strand is the only option. Still, your words bring me concern. The destruction of the seals is not something we should undertake without careful discussion. The Lord Dragon charged me with raising him an army, and I have done so. If you provide the gateways you have promised, I will bring some troops to this meeting place, along with the loyal High Lords and Ladies. Be warned, however, that the Seanchan presence to my west continues to weigh heavily upon my mind. The bulk of my armies must remain behind.

haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə, kɪŋ ə tɛɹ bɪniθ ðə ɹul ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹænd ælθɹ ɛɡɔwin tæp ðə ʃit wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. ʃi wɑz ɪmpɹɛst - dɑɹlɪn hæd kəmɪɾəd ɪz wɝdz tə peɪpɝ, ɹæðɝ ðən sɛndɪŋ ə mɛsənʒɝ wɪð əm mɛmɝaɪzd. ɪf ə mɛsənʒɝ fɛl ɪndə ðə ɹɔŋ hænz, hɪz wɝdz kəɾ ɔlweɪz bi dɪnaɪd. kənvɪktɪŋ ə mæn ə tʃɹizən beɪst ɑn ðə tɛstəmoʊni ʌv wʌn mɛsənʒɝ wɑz dɪfəkəlt. wɝdz ɑn peɪpɝ, haʊɛvɝ . . . boʊld. baɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðɛm, dɑɹlɪn sɛd, "aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ ɪf ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən dɪskʌvɝz wʌɾ aɪ hæv ɹɪɾən. aɪ stæn baɪ ɪt."

High Lord Darlin Sisnera, King of Tear beneath the rule of the Dragon Reborn Rand al'Thor Egawene tapped the sheet with one finger. She was impressed - Darlin had committed his words to paper, rather than sending a messenger with them memorized. If a messenger fell into the wrong hands, his words could always be denied. Convicting a man of treason based on the testimony of one messenger was difficult. Words on paper, however . . . Bold. By writing them, Darlin said, "I do not care if the Lord Dragon discovers what I have written. I stand by it."

bʌt livɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə bʌlk ə hɪz ɑɹmi? ðət wəd nɑt du. ɛɡwin ɪŋkt əɹ pɛn. kɪŋ dɑɹlɪn. jəɹ kənsɝn fəɹ jəɹ kɪŋdəm ɪz wɛl mɛʒɝd, əz ɪz jəɹ lɔɪəlti tə ðə mæn jə fɑloʊ.

But leaving behind the bulk of his army? That would not do. Egwene inked her pen. King Darlin. Your concern for your kingdom is well measured, as is your loyalty to the man you follow.

aɪ noʊ ðət ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ə deɪnʒɝ tə tɛɹ, bʌt lɛɾ əs nɑt fɝɡɛt ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn, nɑt ðə sintʃæn, ɪz əɹ pɹaɪmɛɹi kənsɝn dʊɹɪŋ ðiz wɝst ə deɪz. pɝhæps ɪts izi tə θɪŋk jɝsɛlf seɪf fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑləks wən soʊ dɪstən fɹəm ðə bæɾəl laɪnz, bʌt haʊ wɪl jə fil wʌns ðə kʊʃənz ɑfændɝ ən kɛɹhin əv fɔlən? jə ɑɹ sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ðə sintʃæn baɪ hʌnʒɹədz ə maɪlz.

I know that the Seanchan are a danger to Tear, but let us not forget that the Dark One, not the Seanchan, is our primary concern during these worst of days. Perhaps it is easy to think yourself safe from the Trollocs when so distant from the battle lines, but how will you feel once the cushions ofAndor and Cairhien have fallen? You are separated from the Seanchan by hundreds of miles.

ɛɡwin pɔzd. tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd bɪn sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ðə sintʃæn baɪ hʌnʒɹədz ə maɪlz, ən hæd nɪɹli bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd. hi wɑz ɹaɪt tə bi əfɹeɪd, ən i wɑz ə ɡʊd kɪŋ fəɹ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɪt. bʌt ʃi niɾəd ɪz ɑɹmi ət ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ. pɝhæps ʃi kəɾ ɔfɝ ə weɪ fəɹ ɪm tə boʊθ bi seɪf ən hɛlp wɪð ɹænd.

Egwene paused. Tar Valon had been separated from the Seanchan by hundreds of miles, and had nearly been destroyed. He was right to be afraid, and he was a good king for considering it. But she needed his army at the Field of Merrilor. Perhaps she could offer a way for him to both be safe and help with Rand.

ɪljən hoʊlz fəɹ naʊ, ʃi ɹoʊt. ən ɡɪvz jə ə bʌfɝ bɪtwin ðə sintʃæn ən jɝsɛlf əl pɹəvaɪd jə wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz ən ə pɹɑməs. ɪf ðə sintʃæn muv əɡɛns tɛɹ, wʌn wɪl ɡɪv jə ɡeɪtweɪz soʊ jə kən ɹɪtɝn ɪmiɾiətli ən dɪfɛn jəɹ neɪʃən.

Illian holds for now, she wrote. And gives you a buffer between the Seanchan and yourself I will provide you with gateways and a promise. If the Seanchan move against Tear, 1 will give you gateways so you can return immediately and defend your nation.

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. tʃænsəz wɝ ɡʊd ðət ðə sintʃæn hæd tʃɹævlɪŋ naʊ. noʊbɑdi wɑz seɪf fɹəm ðɛm, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɑɹ əɹ kloʊs ðeɪ maɪt bi. ɪf ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stʃɹaɪk fəɹ tɛɹ, ivən ɡɪvɪŋ dɑɹlɪn ɡeɪtweɪz bæk maɪt nɑt bi ɪnʌf tə hɛlp.

She hesitated. Chances were good that the Seanchan had Traveling now. Nobody was safe from them, no matter how far or close they might be. If they decided to strike for Tear, even giving Darlin gateways back might not be enough to help.

ʃi fɛlt ə ʃɪvɝ, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ əɹ oʊn taɪm wɪð ðə sintʃæn, kæptɪv əz ə deɪmeɪn. ʃi loʊðd əm wɪð ə heɪtʃɹəd ðət səmtaɪmz wɝid hɝ. bʌt dæɹɪənz səpɔɹt wɑz ɪsɛnʃəl tə hɝ plænz. ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ ən kəntɪnjud ɹaɪɾɪŋ.

She felt a shiver, remembering her own time with the Seanchan, captive as a damane. She loathed them with a hatred that sometimes worried her. But Dariin's support was essential to her plans. She gritted her teeth and continued writing.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn mʌst si əɹ fʊl fɔɹsɪz mɑɹʃəl tə əpoʊz ɪz bɹæʃ ɪntɛntʃənz. ɪf i siz ðɪs əz hæfhɑɹɾɪd, wɪl nɛvɝ dɪsweɪɾ ɪm fɹəm ɪz kɔɹs. pliz kʌm wɪð ɔl ə jəɹ tʃɹups.

The Dragon Reborn must see our full forces marshaled to oppose his brash intentions. If he sees this as halfhearted, we will never dissuade him from his course. Please come with all of your troops.

ʃi sændɪd ðə lɛɾɝ, ðən foʊldəɾ ən sild ɪt. dɑɹlɪn ən ɪleɪn wɝ mɑnɑɹks ə tu ʌv ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl kɪŋdəmz. boʊθ wɝ vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ plænz.

She sanded the letter, then folded and sealed it. Darlin and Elayne were monarchs of two of the most powerful kingdoms. Both were very important to her plans.

nɛkst ʃi wəd ɹɪspɑn tə ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ɡɹɛɡɹɪn dɛn lʌʃɪnoʊz ʌv ɪljən.

Next she would respond to a letter from Gregorin den Lushenos of Illian.

ʃi hædn jɛt toʊld ɪm dɝɛkli ðət ʃi hæd mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt hæd hɪntəɾ əɾ ɪt. ʃiɾ ɔlsoʊ spoʊkən tə mæɾɪn hɪmsɛlf, lɛɾɪŋ ɪm noʊ hi wɑz fɹi tə liv, ɪf i wɪʃt. ʃi wəd nɑt bi ɪn ðə hæbəɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ mɑnɑɹks əɡɛns ðɛɹ wɪl.

She hadn't yet told him directly that she had Mattin Stepaneos at the White Tower, but had hinted at it. She'd also spoken to Mattin himself, letting him know he was free to leave, if he wished. She would not be in the habit of holding monarchs against their will.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, mæɾɪn wɑz naʊ əfɹeɪd fəɹ ɪz laɪf, ʃəɾ i ɹɪtɝn. hid bɪn ɡɔn tu lɔŋ, ən i vjuɾ ɪljən əz biɪŋ ɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹeɪ-bɔɹnz pɑkət. wɪtʃ ɪt pɹɑbli wɑz. wʌɾ ə mɛs.

Unfortunately, Mattin was now afraid for his life, should he return. He'd been gone too long, and he viewed Illian as being in the Dragon Re-born's pocket. Which it probably was. What a mess.

wʌn pɹɑbləm əɾ ə taɪm. ɡɹɛɡɹɪn, ðə stuɝɾ ɪn ɪljən, wɑz vɛɹi hɛzɪɾənt tə səpɔɹɾ əɹ kɑz - hi simd mɔɹ ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ɹænd ðən dɑɹlɪn wɑz, ən ðə sintʃæn wɝ nɑɾ ə dɪstən kənsɝn fəɹ hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ pɹæktəkli paʊndɪŋ ɑn ɪz sɪɾi ɡeɪts.

One problem at a time. Gregorin, the steward in Illian, was very hesitant to support her cause - he seemed more intimidated by Rand than Darlin was, and the Seanchan were not a distant concern for him. They were practically pounding on his city gates.

ʃi ɹoʊt ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ə fɝm lɛɾɝ, ɡɪvɪŋ ə pɹɑməs laɪk ðə wʌn ʃid ɡɪvən dɑɹlɪn. pɝhæps ʃi kəɾ ɝeɪnʒ tə kip mæɾɪn əweɪ - sʌmθɪŋ boʊθ mɛn maɪt wɑnt, ðoʊ ʃi wʊdn lɛt ɡɹɛɡɹɪn noʊ ðət - ɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ɪm bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmiz nɔɹθwɝd.

She wrote Gregorin a firm letter, giving a promise like the one she'd given Darlin. Perhaps she could arrange to keep Mattin away - something both men might want, though she wouldn't let Gregorin know that - in exchange for him bringing his armies northward.

oʊblikli, ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. ʃi wɑz juzɪŋ ɹændz pɹɑkləmeɪʃən əz ə bikən baɪ wɪtʃ tə ɡæðɝ ən taɪ ðə mɑnɑɹks tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðeɪ wəd kʌm tə səpɔɹɾ əɹ ɑɹɡjəməns əɡɛns bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə silz. bʌɾ ɪn ði ɛnd, ðeɪ wəd sɝv hjumənkaɪn ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl.

Obliquely, she realized what she was doing. She was using Rand's proclamation as a beacon by which to gather and tie the monarchs to the White Tower. They would come to support her arguments against breaking the seals. But in the end, they would serve humankind in the Last Battle.

ə nɑk keɪm əɾ əɹ dɔɹ. ʃi lʊkt ʌp əz sɪlviænə pikt ɪn. ðə wʊmən hɛld ʌp ə lɛɾɝ. ɪt wɑz kɝl taɪtli fɹəm hævɪŋ bɪn kæɹiɾ ɪn baɪ pɪdʒən.

A knock came at her door. She looked up as Silviana peeked in. The woman held up a letter. It was curled tightly from having been carried in by pigeon.

"jɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɪz ɡɹɪm," ɛɡwin noʊɾəd.

"Your expression is grim," Egwene noted.

"ði ɪnveɪʒən əz bɪɡʌn," ʃi sɛd. "wɑtʃtaʊɝz əkɹɔs ðə blaɪt-bɔɹɾɝ ɡoʊ saɪlənt, wʌn əɾ ə taɪm. weɪvz ə tʃɹɑləks ədvæns bɪniθ klaʊdz ðət bɔɪl blæk. kændɝ, ɝæfəl ən sɑldɑiə ɑɹ ət wɔɹ."

"The invasion has begun," she said. "Watchtowers across the Blight-border go silent, one at a time. Waves of Trollocs advance beneath clouds that boil black. Kandor, Arafel and Saldaea are at war."

"du ðeɪ hoʊld?" ɛɡwin æskt wɪð ə spaɪk ə fɪɹ.

"Do they hold?" Egwene asked with a spike of fear.

"jɛs," sɪlviænə sɛd. "bʌt nuz ɪz ənsɝɾən ən pismil. ðɪs lɛɾɝ - wɪtʃ ɪz fɹəm ən aɪz- ænd-ɪɹz aɪ tʃɹʌst - kleɪmz ðəɾ ən əsɔl ðɪs mæsɪv əz nɑt bɪn sin sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz."

"Yes," Silviana said. "But news is uncertain and piecemeal. This letter - which is from an eyes- and-ears I trust - claims that an assault this massive has not been seen since the Trolloc Wars."

ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "wʌɾ ə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp?"

Egwene took a deep breath. "What of Tarwin's Gap?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ."

"I don't know."

"faɪn aʊt. kɔl sɪuən ɪn hɪɹ. ʃi maɪɾ əv mɔɹ. ðə blu nɛtwɝk ɪz ðə moʊst ɪkstɛnsɪv."

"Find out. Call Siuan in here. She might have more. The Blue network is the most extensive."

sɪuən wʊdnt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi wəɾ əv əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn ɪt.

Siuan wouldn't know everything, of course, but she would have her fingers in it.

sɪlviænə nɑɾəd kɝtli. ʃi dɪdn seɪ ði ɑbviəs - ðət ðə blu nɛtwɝk wɑz ðə blu ədʒɑz, nɑt tə bi pɹiɛmptɪd baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn. wɛl, ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz ət hænd. səm kənsɛʃənz hæd tə bi meɪd.

Silviana nodded curtly. She didn't say the obvious - that the Blue network was the Blue Ajah's, not to be preempted by the Amyrlin. Well, the Last Battle was at hand. Some concessions had to be made.

sɪlviænə kloʊz ðə dɔɹ sɔfli, ən ɛɡwin pɪkt ʌp əɹ pɛn tə fɪnɪʃ əɹ skɹid tə ɡɹɛɡɹɪn.

Silviana closed the door softly, and Egwene picked up her pen to finish her screed to Gregorin.

ʃi wɑz ɪntɝʌptɪd baɪ ənʌðɝ nɑk, ðɪs wʌn mʌtʃ ɝnɔɹ heɪsti. sɪlviænə θɹu oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ə sɛkən leɪɾɝ.

She was interrupted by another knock, this one much rnore hasty. Silviana threw open the door a second later.

"mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd. "ðeɪɹ miɾɪŋ. əz jə sɛd ðeɪ wʊd!"

"Mother," she said. "They're meeting. As you said they would!"

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə stæb ʌv ənɔɪəns. ʃi kɑmli pʊt daʊn əɹ pɛn ən stʊd. "lɛɾ əs bi tə ɪt, ðɛn."

Egwene felt a stab of annoyance. She calmly put down her pen and stood. "Let us be to it, then."

ʃi wɔk fɹəm əɹ stʌɾi, peɪs hɝid. ɪn ðə kipɝz æntətʃæmbɝ, ʃi pæst ə pɛɹ ʌv æksɛptɪd - nɪkoʊlə, hu hæd dʒʌs bɪn ɹeɪzd, ən nɪsə. ʃid laɪk əm boʊθ ɹeɪz tə ðə ʃɔl bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

She walked from her study, pace hurried. In the Keeper's antechamber, she passed a pair of Accepted - Nicola, who had just been raised, and Nissa. She'd like them both raised to the shawl before the Last Battle.

ðeɪ wɝ jʌŋ, bʌt paʊɝfəl, ən ɛvɹi sɪstɝ wəd bi niɾəd - ivən wʌn hu, laɪk nɪkoʊlə, hæd pɹuv tə hæv tɛɹəbəl dʒʌdʒmən ɪn ðə pæst.

They were young, but powerful, and every sister would be needed - even one who, like Nicola, had proved to have terrible judgment in the past.

ðiz tu hæd bɹɔt ðə nuz əbaʊt ðə hɔl; ðə nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd wɝ əmʌŋ ðə moʊs lɔɪəl tə ɛɡwin, bʌt wɝ ɔfən ɪɡnɔɹd baɪ ðə sɪstɝz. fəɹ naʊ, ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪn əz ɛɡwin ən sɪlviænə hɝid təwɔɹd ðə hɔl.

These two had brought the news about the Hall; the novices and Accepted were among the most loyal to Egwene, but were often ignored by the sisters. For now, they remained behind as Egwene and Silviana hurried toward the Hall.

"aɪ kæn bɪliv ðeɪ wəd tʃɹaɪ ðɪs," sɪlviænə sɛd sɔfli əz ðeɪ wɔkt.

"I can't believe they would try this," Silviana said softly as they walked.

"ɪts nɑt wʌt jə θɪŋk," ɛɡwin ɡɛst. "ðeɪ woʊn tʃɹaɪ tə dɪpoʊz mi. ðə dɪvɪʒən ɪz tu fɹɛʃ ɪn ðɛɹ maɪnz."

"It's not what you think," Egwene guessed. "They won't try to depose me. The division is too fresh in their minds."

"ðɛn waɪ mit wɪθaʊt ju?"

"Then why meet without you?"

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ weɪz tə muv əɡɛnst ən æmɪɝlɪn wɪθaʊt dəpoʊzɪŋ hɝ."

"There are ways to move against an Amyrlin without deposing her."

ʃid bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðɪs fəɹ səm taɪm, bʌt ðət dɪdn meɪk ɪɾ ɛni lɛs fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ. ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊd, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ə mæɾɝ ə taɪm bɪfɔɹ sʌmwʌn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ ɹɛntʃɪŋ paʊɝ fɹəm hɝ.

She'd been expecting this for some time, but that didn't make it any less frustrating. Aes Sedai would, unfortunately, be Aes Sedai. It had only been a matter of time before someone decided to try wrenching power from her.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə hɔl. ɛɡwin pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹz ən stɛpt ɪn. hɝ əpɪɹəns wɑz mɛt wɪð kul ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪzəz. ðə sits wɝn ɔl fɪld, bʌt tu-θɝdz ə ðɛm wɝ. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si θɹi ɹɛd sɪɾɝz. wʌɾ ə pɛvɑɹə ən dʒəvɪnʒɹə? ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət ðɛɹ ɪkstɛndəɾ æbsəns dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs taɪm hæd pɹɑmptəd ðə ɹɛd tə ækʃən. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɹipleɪs baɪ ɹɛtʃɪn ən vɪɹiə kɑnɹəl. ðə sɪstɝz wɝ ði oʊnli sɪblɪŋz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, naʊ ðət vændin ən æɾɪliz wɝ dɛd; ən ɑd tʃɔɪs, bʌt nɑɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd.

They reached the Hall. Egwene pushed open the doors and stepped in. Her appearance was met with cool Aes Sedai gazes. The seats weren't all filled, but two-thirds of them were. She was surprised to see three Red Sitters. What of Pevara and Javindhra? It appeared that their extended absence during this time had prompted the Red to action. They had been replaced by Raechin and Viria Connoral. The sisters were the only siblings in the White Tower, now that Vandene and Adeleas were dead; an odd choice, but not unexpected.

boʊθ ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn wɝ ɪn ətɛndəns. ðeɪ mɛɾ ɛɡwinz ɡeɪz ivənli. haʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ tə si ðɛm hɪɹ wɪð soʊ mɛni sɪstɝz u ðeɪ hæd bɪn əɾ ɑdz wɪð. ə kɑmən foʊ - ɛɡwin - kəd hil ɛni nʌmbɝ ə ɹɪfs. ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn plizd ət ðæt, pɝhæps.

Both Romanda and Lelaine were in attendance. They met Egwene's gaze evenly. How strange to see them here with so many sisters who they had been at odds with. A common foe - Egwene - could heal any number of rifts. She should have been pleased at that, perhaps.

ləleɪn wɑz ði oʊnli blu, ən ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ oʊnli wʌn bɹaʊn: tɑkimə, hu lʊk sɪk. ði aɪvɝi-skɪn bɹaʊn wʊdn miɾ ɛɡwinz ɡeɪz. ðəɹ wɝ tu waɪts, tu jɛloʊz -  ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɹoʊmændə - tu ɡɹeɪz, ən ɔl θɹi ɡɹinz. ɛɡwin ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ wən ʃi sɔ ðæt.

Lelaine was the only Blue, and there was also only one Brown: Takima, who looked sick. The ivory-skinned Brown wouldn't meet Egwene's gaze. There were two Whites, two Yellows -  including Romanda - two Grays, and all three Greens. Egwene gritted her teeth when she saw that.

ðət wɑz ði ədʒɑ ʃi wəɾ əv dʒɔɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪv əɹ ðə moʊst ɡɹif!

That was the Ajah she would have joined, but it gave her the most grief!

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt tʃæstaɪz əm fəɹ miɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt hɝ; ʃi sɪmpli stʃɹoʊd daʊn bɪtwin ðɛm, sɪlviænə ənaʊnsɪŋ hɝ. ɛɡwin tɝn ən sæt daʊn ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, hɝ bæk tə ðə hjudʒ ɹoʊz wɪndoʊ.

Egwene did not chastise them for meeting without her; she simply strode down between them, Silviana announcing her. Egwene turned and sat down on the Amyrlin Seat, her back to the huge rose window.

ðɛɹ, ʃi sæt kwaɪətli.

There, she sat quietly.

"wɛl?" ɹoʊmændə faɪnəli æskt. hɝ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ʌp ɪn ə bʌn, ʃi lʊk laɪk ə mʌðɝ wʊlf sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ðə lɛdʒ aʊt fɹʌn ə hɝ dɛn. "ɑɹ jə ɡoʊ-ɪŋ tə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, mʌðɝ?"

"Well?" Romanda finally asked. Her gray hair up in a bun, she looked like a mother wolf sitting atop the ledge out front of her den. "Are you go-ing to say anything, Mother?"

"ju dɪd nɑɾ ɪnfɔɹm mi ʌv ðɪs miɾɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "soʊ aɪ əsum jə də nɑt wɑn maɪ wɝdz. aɪ hæv kʌm mɪɹli tə wɑtʃ."

"You did not inform me of this meeting," Egwene said, "so I assume you do not want my words. I have come merely to watch."

ðət sim tə meɪk əm mɔɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. sɪlviænə wɔk tə hɝ saɪd, bɹændɪʃɪŋ wʌn ə hɝ bɛst ɪkspɹɛʃənz ə dɪsplɛʒɝ.

That seemed to make them more uncomfortable. Silviana walked to her side, brandishing one of her best expressions of displeasure.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," ɹubɪn sɛd. "aɪ bɪliv wi wɝ gɑnə hɪɹ fɹəm sɛɝɔɪjə nɛkst."

"All right, then," Rubinde said. "I believe we were going to hear from Saroiya next."

ðə blɑki waɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz u hæd lɛf ðə taʊɝ wən ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɹeɪzd, bʌt ʃi hæd meɪɾ əɹ ʃɛɹ ə tʃɹʌbəl ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɝ hɪɹ. ðə wʊmən stʊd, pɔɪntɪdli nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin. "aɪ wɪl æd maɪ tɛstəmoʊni. dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz ʌv. . . ənsɝɾənti wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ" - ðət wəd min ðə dɪvɪʒən; fju sɪstɝz laɪk tə spik ʌv ɪɾ aʊtʃɹaɪt - "ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪɾ ɪɡzækli əz ɹoʊmændə ɪndəkeɪɾəd. wi wɝ teɪkən baɪ sɝpɹaɪz wən ʃi kɔl fəɹ ə dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ.

The blocky White was one of the Sitters who had left the Tower when Elaida was raised, but she had made her share of trouble in Salidar. Egwene was not surprised to see her here. The woman stood, pointedly not looking at Egwene. "I will add my testimony. During the days of. . . uncertainty within the Tower" - that would mean the division; few sisters liked to speak of it outright - "the Amyrlin did exactly as Romanda indicated. We were taken by surprise when she called for a declaration of war.

"wɪðɪn ðə lɔ, ðəɹ ɑɹ pɹəvɪʒənz ðət ɡɪv ði æmɪɝlɪn ɔlmoʊs toʊɾəl paʊɝ wən əfɪʃəl wɔɹ ɪz dɪklɛɹd. baɪ biɪŋ ɡoʊɾɪd ɪndə meɪkɪŋ wɔɹ wɪð ɪleɪɾə, wi ɡeɪv ði æmɪɝlɪn ðə minz tə səbdʒɛk ðə hɔl tə hɝ wɪl." ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, bʌt dɪd nɑt tɝn tə ɛɡwin. "ɪɾ ɪz maɪ əpɪnjən ðət ʃɪl tʃɹaɪ sʌmθɪŋ sɪməlɝ əɡɛn. ðət mʌs bi pɹɪvɛntɪd. ðə hɔl ɪz mɛn tə bi ə bæləns əpɑn ði æmɪɝlɪnz paʊɝ."

"Within the law, there are provisions that give the Amyrlin almost total power when official war is declared. By being goaded into making war with Elaida, we gave the Amyrlin the means to subject the Hall to her will." She looked around the room, but did not turn to Egwene. "It is my opinion that she will try something similar again. That must be prevented. The Hall is meant to be a balance upon the Amyrlin's power."

ʃi sæt daʊn.

She sat down.

hɪɹɪŋ ðə wɝdz æktʃəli  ɹɪlivd ɛɡwin. wʌn kəd nɛvɝ bi sɝɾən wʌt kaɪnz ə skimɪŋ wɝ hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðɪs miɾɪŋ mɛn əɹ plænz wɝ pɹəsiɾɪŋ əz hoʊpt, ən ðəɾ əɹ ɛnəmiz - ɔɹ, wɛl, hɝ ɹɪlʌktən ælaɪz - hædn sin wʌt ʃi wɑz ɹɪli duɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ bɪzi ɹiæktɪŋ tə θɪŋz ʃid dʌn mʌnθs əɡoʊ.

Hearing the words actually relieved Egwene. One could never be certain what kinds of scheming were happening in the White Tower. This meeting meant her plans were proceeding as hoped, and that her enemies - or, well, her reluctant allies - hadn't seen what she was really doing. They were busy reacting to things she'd done months ago.

ðət dɪdn min ðeɪ wɝn deɪnʒɝəs. bʌt wən ə pɝsən æntɪsəpeɪɾəd deɪnʒɝ, ɪt kəd bi hændəld.

That didn't mean they weren't dangerous. But when a person anticipated danger, it could be handled.

"wʌt kən wi du?" mæɡlə æskt. ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. "tə bi pɹuɾənt, aɪ min. tə meɪk sɝɾən ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪz ɪn noʊ weɪ lɪməɾəd."

"What can we do?" Magla asked. She glanced at Egwene. "To be prudent, I mean. To make certain the Hall of the Tower is in no way limited."

"wi kænɑt dɪklɛɹ wɔɹ," ləleɪn sɛd fɝmli.

"We cannot declare war," Lelaine said firmly.

"æn jɛt, tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt?" vɛɹɪlɪn sɛd. "wɔɹ ɪz dɪklɛɹd bɪtwin hævz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt nɑɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ?"

"And yet, to avoid it?" Varilin said. "War is declared between halves of the White Tower, but not against the Shadow?"

"wɔɹ," tɑkimə sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli, "ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪklɛɹɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ.

"War," Takima said hesitantly, "is already declared against the Shadow.

nid ðəɹ bi ən əfɪʃəl pɹɑkləmeɪʃən? ɪz nɑɾ əɹ ɛɡzɪstəns ɪnʌf? ɪn-did, də nɑt ði oʊðz meɪk əɹ pəzɪʃən klɪɹ?"

Need there be an official proclamation? Is not our existence enough? In-deed, do not the oaths make our position clear?"

"bʌt wi mʌs meɪk səm kaɪndə dɛklɝeɪʃən," ɹoʊmændə sɛd. ʃi wɑz ɛldəst əmʌŋ ðɛm, ən wəd bi ðə wʌn ɹʌnɪŋ ðə miɾɪŋ. "sʌm-θɪŋ tə meɪk ðə pəzɪʃən ə ðə hɔl noʊn, tə dɪsweɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn fɹəm ən ɪmpɹuɾənt kɔl fəɹ wɔɹ."

"But we must make some kind of declaration," Romanda said. She was eldest among them, and would be the one running the meeting. "Some-thing to make the position of the Hall known, to dissuade the Amyrlin from an imprudent call for war."

ɹoʊmændə dɪdn sim ɪmbɛɹəst əɾ ɔl baɪ wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn hɪɹ. ʃi lʊk dɝɛkli əɾ ɛɡwin. noʊ, ʃi ən ləleɪn wəd nɑt kwɪkli fɝɡɪv ɛɡwin fəɹ tʃuzɪŋ ə ɹɛɾ əz əɹ kipɝ.

Romanda didn't seem embarrassed at all by what they had done here. She looked directly at Egwene. No, she and Lelaine would not quickly forgive Egwene for choosing a Red as her Keeper.

"bʌt haʊ wəd wi sɛn sətʃ ə mɛsədʒ?" ændaɪə æskt. "aɪ min, wʌɾ ɑɹ wi tə du? meɪk ə pɹənaʊnsmən fɹəm ðə hɔl ðət ðəɹ woʊn bi ə dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ? wəd ðət nɑt saʊn ɹɪdɪkjələs?"

"But how would we send such a message?" Andaya asked. "I mean, what are we to do? Make a pronouncement from the Hall that there won't be a declaration of war? Would that not sound ridiculous?"

ðə wɪmən fɛl saɪlənt. ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf nɑɾɪŋ, ðoʊ nɑt spəsɪfɪkli tə wʌt wɑz biɪŋ sɛd. ʃi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz θɹu ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl sɝkəmstænsəz. lɛft əloʊn, ðə hɔl wəd tʃɹaɪ tə ɪstæblɪʃ ɪts paʊɝ əz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən hɝz. ðɪs deɪ kəɾ izəli hæv mɛn ə stɛp təwɔɹd ðæt. ði æmɪɝlɪn sits stʃɹɛŋkθ hæd nɑt bɪn kɑnstən θɹu ðə sɛntʃɝiz -  wʌn kəd ɹul ɔlmoʊs toʊɾəli waɪl ənʌðɝ wɑz kəntʃɹoʊl baɪ ðə sɪɾɝz.

The women fell silent. Egwene found herself nodding, though not specifically to what was being said. She had been raised through unconventional circumstances. Left alone, the Hall would try to establish its power as greater than hers. This day could easily have meant a step toward that. The Amyrlin Seat's strength had not been constant through the centuries -  one could rule almost totally while another was controlled by the Sitters.

"aɪ bɪliv ðə hɔl æks ɪn wɪzdəm," ɛɡwin sɛd, spikɪŋ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli.

"I believe the Hall acts in wisdom," Egwene said, speaking very carefully.

ðə sɪɾɝz tɝn tə hɝ. səm lʊkt ɹɪlivd. ðoʊz u wɝ mɔɹ fəmɪljɝ wɪð hɝ, haʊɛvɝ, lʊk səspɪʃəs. wɛl, ðət wɑz ɡʊd. bɛɾɝ ðeɪ ɹəɡɑɹɾ əɹ əz ə θɹɛt ðən əz ə tʃaɪl tə bi bʊlid. ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹɪspɛkt əɹ əz ðɛɹ liɾɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli soʊ mʌtʃ ʃi kəd də wɪð ðə taɪm ɡɪvən.

The Sitters turned to her. Some looked relieved. Those who were more familiar with her, however, looked suspicious. Well, that was good. Better they regard her as a threat than as a child to be bullied. She hoped they would eventually respect her as their leader, but there was only so much she could do with the time given.

"ðə wɔɹ bɪtwin fækʃənz wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ wɑz ə dɪfɹən taɪp ə bæɾəl," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud.

"The war between factions within the Tower was a different type of battle," Egwene continued.

"ɪt wɑz dipli ən ɪndɪvɪdʒuəli maɪ bæɾəl, əz æmɪɝlɪn, fəɹ ðət dɪvɪʒən wɑz ɪnɪʃəli əbaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

"It was deeply and individually my battle, as Amyrlin, for that division was initially about the Amyrlin Seat.

"bʌt ðə wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz mɔɹ væs ðən ɛni wʌn pɝsən. ɪts ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən jə əɹ aɪ, ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɪts ðə wɔɹ ʌv ɔl laɪf ən kɹieɪʃən, fɹəm ðə moʊs dɛstətuɾ ə bɛɡɝz tə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə kwinz."

"But the war against the Shadow is more vast than any one person. It is greater than you or I, greater than the White Tower. It is the war of all life and creation, from the most destitute of beggars to the most powerful of queens."

ðə sɪɾɝz kənsɪɾɝd ðəɾ ɪn saɪləns.

The Sitters considered that in silence.

ɹoʊmændə spoʊk fɝst. "æn soʊ jə wəd nɑɾ əpoʊz ðə hɔl teɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ pɹɑsəkjuʃən ə ðə wɔɹ, mænɪdʒɪŋ dʒɛnɝəl bɹaɪnz ɑɹmiz ən ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd?"

Romanda spoke first. "And so you would not oppose the Hall taking over prosecution of the war, managing General Bryne's armies and the Tower Guard?"

ðət dɪpɛnz," ɛɡwin sɛd, "əpɑn haʊ ðə pɹəvɪʒən wɑz wɝɾɪd." ðəɹ wɑz muvmən ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd, ən sɹɪn bʌsəld ɪndə ðə hɔl, əkʌmpənid baɪ dʒɑnjə fɹɛnd. ðeɪ ʃɑt tɑkimə wɪðɝɪŋ ɡlænsɪz, ən ʃi ʃɹæŋk daʊn laɪk ə θɹɛɾənd bɝd. sɹɪn ən ɛɡwinz ʌðɝ səpɔɹɾɝz wʊɾə bɪn ɪnfɔɹmd ə ðɪs miɾɪŋ dʒʌst æftɝ ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf wɑz.

That depends," Egwene said, "upon how the provision was worded." There was movement in the hallway outside, and Saerin bustled into the Hall, accompanied by Janya Frende. They shot Takima withering glances, and she shrank down like a threatened bird. Saerin and Egwene's other supporters would have been informed of this meeting just after Egwene herself was.

ɹoʊmændə klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. "pɝhæps wi ʃəd si ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛni-θɪŋ ɪn ðə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ ðət kən hɛlp."

Romanda cleared her throat. "Perhaps we should see if there is any-thing in the Law of War that can help."

"aɪm sɝɾən juv stʌɾid ɪt kwaɪt θɝoʊli naʊ, ɹoʊmændə" ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə pɹəpoʊz?"

"I'm certain you have studied it quite thoroughly now, Romanda" Egwene said. "What is it you propose?"

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə pɹəvɪʒən fəɹ ðə hɔl teɪkɪŋ ʌp pɹɑsəkjuʃən ʌv ə wɔɹ" ɹoʊmændə sɛd.

"There is a provision for the Hall taking up prosecution of a war" Romanda said.

"ðæt ɹikwaɪɝz ði æmɪɝlɪnz əsɛnt," ɛɡwin sɛɾ aɪdli. ɪf ðət wɑz ɹoʊmændəz ɡeɪm, ðən haʊ hæd ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɡɛɾ ɛɡwin ɛs əpɹuvəl æftɝ miɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt hɝ? pɝhæps ʃid hæɾ ə dɪfɹən plæn.

"That requires the Amyrlin's assent," Egwene said idly. If that was Romandas game, then how had she intended to get Egwene s approval after meeting without her? Perhaps she'd had a different plan.

"jɛs, ɪt wəd ɹikwaɪɝ ði æmɪɝlɪnz əɡɹimənt," sɛd ɹɛtʃɪn. ʃi wɑz ə tɔl, dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən, ən laɪk tə wɛɹ əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə kɔɪl ə bɹeɪdz ətɑp əɹ hɛd. "bʌt jə sɛd ðət jə θɔɾ əs waɪz tə teɪk ðɪs mɛʒɝ."

"Yes, it would require the Amyrlin's agreement," said Raechin. She was a tall, dark-haired woman, and liked to wear her hair in a coil of braids atop her head. "But you said that you thought us wise to take this measure."

"wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn əz ɪf ʃi wɝ biɪŋ pɹɛst ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ, "əɡɹiɪŋ wɪð ðə hɔl ɪz kwaɪt dɪfɹən fɹəm əlaʊɪŋ ə pɹəvɪʒən tə bæn mi fɹəm ðə deɪ-tə-deɪ wɝkɪŋz ə ði ɑɹmi. wʌɾ ɪz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit tə du, ɪf nɑt si tə ðə wɔɹ?"

"Well," Egwene said, trying to sound as if she were being pressed into a corner, "agreeing with the Hall is quite different from allowing a provision to ban me from the day-to-day workings of the army. What is the Amyrlin Seat to do, if not see to the war?"

"baɪ ɹɪpɔɹts, juv bɪn dɛɾɪkeɪtɪŋ jɝsɛlf tə ɹæŋɡəlɪŋ kɪŋz ən kwinz," ləleɪn sɛd. "ðæt simz ə faɪn tæsk fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn."

"By reports, you've been dedicating yourself to wrangling kings and queens," Lelaine said. "That seems a fine task for the Amyrlin."

"ðɛn jəl stæn fəɹ sətʃ ə pɹəvɪʒən?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðə hɔl siz tə ði ɑɹmi, waɪl aɪm ɡɪvən əθɔɹəɾi fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðə mɑnɑɹks ə ðə wɝld?"

"Then you'll stand for such a provision?" Egwene said. "The Hall sees to the army, while I am given authority for dealing with the monarchs of the world?"

"aɪ. . ." ləleɪn sɛd. "jɛs, aɪd stæn fəɹ ðæt."

"I. . ." Lelaine said. "Yes, I'd stand for that."

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kəɾ əɡɹi," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"I suppose I could agree," Egwene said.

"ʃæl wi pʊɾ ɪt tə ə voʊt?" ɹoʊmændə sɛd kwɪkli, əz ɪf paʊnsɪŋ ɑn ðə moʊmənt.

"Shall we put it to a vote?" Romanda said quickly, as if pouncing on the moment.

"vɛɹi wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd. "hu wɪl stæn fəɹ ðɪs moʊʃən?"

"Very well," Egwene said. "Who will stand for this motion?"

ɹubɪn ɹoʊz tə hɝ fit, ən wɑz dʒɔɪn baɪ feɪsɛl ən fɑɹnə, ði ʌðɝ ɡɹinz. ɹɛtʃɪn ən əɹ sɪstɝ stʊd kwɪkli, ðoʊ bɑɹɑsin wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɛɡwin wɪð aɪz nɛɹoʊd. mæɡlə stʊd nɛkst, ən ɹoʊmændə ɹɪlʌktənli dʒɔɪn hɝ. fɛɹən ɹoʊz sloʊli. ləleɪn wɑz nɛkst. ʃi ən ɹoʊmændə ʃɑt dæɡɝd ɡlænsɪz ət wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Rubinde rose to her feet, and was joined by Faiselle and Farnah, the other Greens. Raechin and her sister stood quickly, though Barasine was watching Egwene with eyes narrowed. Magla stood next, and Romanda reluctantly joined her. Ferane rose slowly. Lelaine was next. She and Romanda shot daggered glances at one another.

ðət wɑz naɪn. ɛɡwinz hɑɹt bit kwɪkli əz ʃi ɡlænst ət tɑkimə. ðə wʊmən sim vɛɹi dɪstɝbd, əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɔɹt θɹu ɛɡwinz plæn. ðə seɪm wɛn fəɹ sɛɝɔɪjə. ðə kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ waɪt stʌɾid ɛɡwin, tʌɡɪŋ əɹ ɪɹ. sʌɾənli, hɝ aɪz wɛnt waɪd, ən ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə spik.

That was nine. Egwene's heart beat quickly as she glanced at Takima. The woman seemed very disturbed, as if trying to sort through Egwene's plan. The same went for Saroiya. The calculating White studied Egwene, tugging her ear. Suddenly, her eyes went wide, and she opened her mouth to speak.

ət ðət moʊmənt, dʌsin ən jukɪɝi ɝaɪvd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum.

At that moment, Doesine and Yukiri arrived, striding into the room.

sɹɪn stʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli. slɪm dʌsin ɡlænst ət ðə wɪmən ɝaʊn hɝ. "wʌt moʊʃən ɑɹ wi stændɪŋ fɔɹ?"

Saerin stood immediately. Slim Doesine glanced at the women around her. "What motion are we standing for?"

"æn ɪmpɔɹɾənt wʌn," sɹɪn sɛd.

"An important one," Saerin said.

""wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz əl stæn fəɹ ɪt, ðɛn."

""Well, I suppose I'll stand for it, then."

"æz wɪl aɪ," jukɪɝi sɛd.

"As will I," Yukiri said.

"ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs ɪz ɡɪvən, ɪt simz," sɹɪn sɛd. "ðə hɔl ɪz ɡɪvən əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝz ɑɹmi, waɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz ɡɪvən əθɔɹəɾi ən ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðə wɝlz mɑnɑɹks."

"The lesser consensus is given, it seems," Saerin said. "The Hall is given authority over the White Tower's army, while the Amyrlin is given authority and responsibility for dealing with the world's monarchs."

"noʊ!" sɛɝɔɪjə sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ tə hɝ fit. "doʊn jə si? hiz ə kɪŋ! hi hoʊlz ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn. juv dʒʌst ɡɪvən ði æmɪɝlɪn soʊl ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!"

"No!" Saroiya said, climbing to her feet. "Don't you see? He is a king! He holds the Laurel Crown. You've just given the Amyrlin sole responsibility for dealing with the Dragon Reborn!"

ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns ɪn ðə hɔl.

There was silence in the Hall.

"wɛl," ɹoʊmændə sɛd, "ʃʊɹli ʃi . . ." ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ʃi tɝnd, siɪŋ ɛɡwinz sɝin feɪs.

"Well," Romanda said, "surely she . . ." She trailed off as she turned, seeing Egwene's serene face.

"aɪ səpoʊz sʌmwʌn ʃəɾ æsk fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs," sɹɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "bʌt juv mænədʒ tə hæŋ jʊɹsɛlvz kwaɪɾ ɪfɪʃənli wɪð ðə lɛsɝ ɹoʊp ɔlɹɛɾi."

"I suppose someone should ask for the greater consensus," Saerin said dryly. "But you've managed to hang yourselves quite efficiently with the lesser rope already."

ɛɡwin stʊd. "aɪ mɛnt wʌɾ aɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə hɔlz tʃɔɪsəz biɪŋ waɪz, ən noʊbɑdi hæz hæŋ hɝsɛlf. ɪts waɪz ə ðə hɔl tə pʊt mi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə dilɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - hɪl niɾ ə fɝm, fəmɪljɝ hænd. jə ɑɹ ɔlsoʊ waɪz tə si ðət ðə dɪteɪlz ə mænɪdʒɪŋ ði ɑɹmi wɝ dɪmændɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ə maɪ ətɛnʃən. jəl wɑnə tʃuz sʌmwʌn əmʌŋ jə tə ɡoʊ θɹu ən əpɹuv ɔl ə dʒɛnɝəl bɹaɪnz səplaɪ ɹɪkwɛsts ən ɹəkɹutmən skimz. aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, ðəɹ ɑɹ ə mʌltətuɾ ə ðɛm.

Egwene stood. "I meant what I said about the Hall's choices being wise, and nobody has hanged herself. It is wise of the Hall to put me in charge of dealing with the Dragon Reborn - he will need a firm, familiar hand. You are also wise to see that the details of managing the army were demanding too much of my attention. You will want to choose someone among you to go through and approve all of General Bryne's supply requests and recruitment schemes. I assure you, there are a multitude of them.

"aɪ æm pliz ðət juv sin ðə nid tə eɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðoʊ aɪm dipli dɪsplizd ət ðə sikɹəɾɪv neɪtʃɝ ə ðɪs miɾɪŋ. də nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə dɪnaɪ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dʌn ɪn sikɹət, ɹoʊmændə. aɪ si jə pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə əbdʒɛkt. ɪf jə wɪʃ tə spik, noʊ ðəɾ əl pɪn jə baɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz ɪndə ænsɝɪŋ dɝɛkli."

"I am pleased that you have seen the need to aid the Amyrlin, though I am deeply displeased at the secretive nature of this meeting. Do not try to deny that it was done in secret, Romanda. I see you preparing to object. If you wish to speak, know that I will pin you by the Three Oaths into answering directly."

ðə jɛloʊ bɪɾ ɔf əɹ kɑmɛnt.

The Yellow bit off her comment.

"haʊ kən jə nɑɾ əv lɝn ðə fulɪʃnəs ʌv æks laɪk ðɪs?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪz jəɹ mɛmɹi soʊ ʃɔɹt?" ʃi lʊkt ət ðə wɪmən ɪn tɝn, ən wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd baɪ ðə nʌmbɝ u wɪnst.

"How can you not have learned the foolishness of acts like this?" Egwene said. "Is your memory so short?" She looked at the women in turn, and was satisfied by the number who winced.

ɪts taɪm," ɛɡwin sɛd, "fɔɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ tə bi meɪd. aɪ pɹəpoʊz ðət ðəɹ bi noʊ fɝðɝ miɾɪŋz ə ðɪs neɪtʃɝ. aɪ pɹəpoʊz ðəɾ ɪt bi ɹɪɾən ɪndə taʊɝ lɔ ðəɾ ɪf ɛni sɪɾɝ livz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, hɝ ədʒɑ mʌst əpɔɪn ə sɝəɡət tə voʊt fəɹ əɹ waɪl æbsənt. aɪ pɹəpoʊz ðəɾ ɪt bi ɹɪɾən ɪndə taʊɝ lɔ ðət noʊ miɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl kən bi kənvin ənlɛs ɛvɹi sɪɾɝ əɹ əɹ sɝəɡəɾ iðɝ ɪz pɹɛzənt, əɹ əz sɛnt wɝd dɝɛkli ðət ʃi kænɑɾ ətɛnd. aɪ pɹəpoʊz ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn mʌs bi ɪnfɔɹmd - ən ɡɪvən ə ɹizənəbəl əmaʊn ə taɪm tə ətɛn ɪf ʃi wɪʃɪz - ʌv ɛvɹi miɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl, seɪv wən ʃi kænɑt bi faʊn əɹ ɪz ɪndɪspoʊzd ɪn səm weɪ."

It is time," Egwene said, "for a change to be made. I propose that there be no further meetings of this nature. I propose that it be written into Tower law that if any Sitter leaves the White Tower, her Ajah must appoint a surrogate to vote for her while absent. I propose that it be written into Tower law that no meeting of the Hall can be convened unless every Sitter or her surrogate either is present, or has sent word directly that she cannot attend. I propose that the Amyrlin must be informed - and given a reasonable amount of time to attend if she wishes - of every meeting of the Hall, save when she cannot be found or is indisposed in some way."

"boʊl tʃeɪnʒəz, mʌðɝ," sɹɪn sɛd. "ju pɹəpoʊz ɔltɝɪŋ tʃɹədɪʃənz ðəɾ əv bɪn ɪstæblɪʃt fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz."

"Bold changes, Mother," Saerin said. "You propose altering traditions that have been established for centuries."

The trial. "Perrin, I don't like this idea." "You're angry about Maighdin."

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪm æŋɡɹi əbaʊt meɪaɪɡdɪn," ʃi sɛd. ðeɪd bɪn θɹu mɔldən təɡɛðɝ, ən ʃi hædn toʊl feɪl ðət ʃi wɑz ðə kwin ə blʌɾi ændɝ? ɪt meɪd feɪl lʊk laɪk ə ful - laɪk ə smɔl-taʊn bɹæɡɝt, ɪkstoʊl-lɪŋ əɹ skɪl wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə pæsɪŋ bleɪdmæstɝ.

"Of course I'm angry about Maighdin," she said. They'd been through Malden together, and she hadn't told Faile that she was the Queen of bloody Andor? It made Faile look like a fool - like a small-town braggart, extol-ling her skill with the sword in front of a passing blademaster.

"ʃi dɪdnt noʊ ɪf ʃi kəd tʃɹʌst ʌs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ʃi wɑz fliɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ɪt simz. aɪɾ əv hɪɾən maɪsɛlf, tu."

"She didn't know if she could trust us," Perrin said. "She was fleeing one of the Forsaken, it seems. I'd have hidden myself, too."

feɪl ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm.

Faile glared at him.

"doʊn lʊk ət mi laɪk ðæt," hi sɛd. "ʃi dɪdn də ɪt tə meɪk jə lʊk bæd, feɪl. ʃi hæɾ əɹ ɹizənz. lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ."

"Don't look at me like that," he said. "She didn't do it to make you look bad, Faile. She had her reasons. Let it go."

ðət meɪɾ əɹ fil ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ; ɪt wɑz soʊ naɪs ðəɾ i wəd stæn ʌp fəɹ hɪmsɛlf naʊ. "wɛl, ɪt meɪks mi wʌndɝ u lini wɪl tɝn aʊt tə bi. səm sintʃæn kwin? mæstɝ ɡɪl, ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən ɪn haɪɾɪŋ?"

That made her feel a little better; it was so nice that he would stand up for himself now. "Well, it makes me wonder who Lini will turn out to be. Some Seanchan queen? Master Gill, the King of Arad Doman in hiding?"

pɛɹɪn smaɪld. "aɪ səspɛk ðəɹ əɹ ətɛndəns. ɡɪl ɪz u hi sɛz i ɪz, ət list. beɪlwɝ ɪz pɹɑbli hævɪŋ ə fɪt fəɹ nɑt hævɪŋ fɪɡjɝd ðɪs aʊt."

Perrin smiled. "I suspect they're her attendants. Gill is who he says he is, at least. Balwer is probably having a fit for not having figured this out."

"aɪ bɛɾ i dɪd fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊt," feɪl sɛd, nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. "pɛɹɪn, aɪ mɛnt wʌɾ aɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl. aɪm wɝid."

"I bet he did figure it out," Faile said, kneeling beside him. "Perrin, I meant what I said about this trial. I'm worried."

"aɪ woʊn lɛt maɪsɛlf bi teɪkən," hi sɛd. "aɪ oʊnli sɛɾ aɪd sɪt θɹu ə tʃɹaɪəl ən ɡɪv əm ə tʃæns tə pɹizɛn ɛvəɾəns."

"I won't let myself be taken," he said. "I only said I'd sit through a trial and give them a chance to present evidence."

"ðɛn wʌts ðə pɔɪnt?" feɪl sɛd.

"Then what's the point?" Faile said.

"ɪt ɡɪvz mi mɔɹ taɪm tə θɪŋk," hi sɛd, "æn ɪt maɪt stɑp mi fɹəm hævɪŋ tə kɪl ðɛm. ðɛɹ kæptən, dəmədʒɹd - sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm smɛlz bɛɾɝ ðən mɛni ʌv ðə ɹɛst. nɑt ɹæbɪd wɪð æŋɡɝ əɹ heɪt. ðɪs wɪl ɡɛɾ əɹ pipəl bæk ən lemi plid maɪ saɪd. ɪt filz ɡʊd fəɹ ə mæn tə bi eɪbəl tə hæv ɪz seɪ. meɪbi ðæts wʌɾ aɪv niɾəd, ɔl ðɪs taɪm."

"It gives me more time to think," he said, "and it might stop me from having to kill them. Their captain, Damodred - something about him smells better than many of the rest. Not rabid with anger or hate. This will get our people back and let me plead my side. It feels good for a man to be able to have his say. Maybe that's what I've needed, all this time."

"wɛl, ɔl ɹaɪt," feɪl sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ, pliz kənsɪɾɝ wɔɹnɪŋ mi ʌv jəɹ plænz."

"Well, all right," Faile said. "But in the future, please consider warning me of your plans."

"aɪ wɪl," hi sɛd, jɔnɪŋ ən laɪɪŋ bæk. "ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪt dɪdn əkɝ tə mi əntɪl ðə læs moʊmənt."

"I will," he said, yawning and lying back. "In truth, it didn't occur to me until the last moment."

feɪl kɛpt əɹ tʌŋ wɪð səm dɪfəkəlti. ət list sʌmθɪŋ ɡʊd hæd kʌm fɹəm ðət pɑɹli.

Faile kept her tongue with some difficulty. At least something good had come from that parley.

ʃid wɑtʃt bɹəleɪn wən ʃid mɛt dəmədʒɹd, ən ʃid ɹɛɹli sin ə wʊmənz aɪz laɪɾ ʌp soʊ bɹaɪtli. feɪl maɪt bi eɪbəl tə meɪk jus ə ðæt.

She'd watched Berelain when she'd met Damodred, and she'd rarely seen a woman's eyes light up so brightly. Faile might be able to make use of that.

ʃi lʊk daʊn. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi snɔɹɪŋ sɔfli.

She looked down. Perrin was already snoring softly.

pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf sɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɪz bæk əɡɛnst sʌmθɪŋ hɑɹɾ ən smuð. ðə tu-dɑɹk, ɔlmoʊst ivəl skaɪ ʌv ðə wʊlf dʒɹim bɔɪld əbʌv ðə fɔɹəst, wɪtʃ wɑz ə mɪkstʃɝ ə fɝ, oʊk ən lɛðɝlif.

Perrin found himself sitting with his back against something hard and smooth. The too-dark, almost evil sky of the wolf dream boiled above the forest, which was a mixture of fir, oak and leatherleaf.

hi stʊɾ ʌp, ðən tɝn ən lʊkt ət wʌɾ i hæd bɪn linɪŋ əɡɛnst. ə mæsɪv stil taʊɝ stʃɹɛtʃt təwɔɹd ðə tɝbjələn skaɪ. tu stʃɹeɪt, wɪð wɔlz ðət lʊk laɪk ə sɪŋɡəl pis ə simləs mɛɾəl, ðə taʊɝ ɪɡzuɾɪd ə kəmplitli ənnætʃɹəl fil.

He stood up, then turned and looked at what he had been leaning against. A massive steel tower stretched toward the turbulent sky. Too straight, with walls that looked like a single piece of seamless metal, the tower exuded a completely unnatural feel.

aɪ toʊl jə ðɪs pleɪs wɑz ivəl, hɑpɝ sɛnt, sʌɾənli sɪɾɪŋ nɛks tə pɝ-ɹɪn. fulɪʃ kʌb.

I told you this place was evil, Hopper sent, suddenly sitting next to Per-rin. Foolish cub.

"aɪ dɪdn kʌm hɪɹ baɪ tʃɔɪs," pɛɹɪn pɹətɛstəd. "aɪ woʊk hɪɹ."

"I didn't come here by choice," Perrin protested. "I woke here."

jəɹ maɪn ɪz foʊkəst ɑn ɪt, hɑpɝ sɛd. əɹ ðə maɪn ʌv wʌn tə hum jə ɑɹ kənɛktəd.

Your mind is focused on it, Hopper said. Or the mind of one to whom you are connected.

"mæt" pɛɹɪn sɛd, wɪθaʊɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ haʊ hi nu. ðə kʌlɝz dɪdn əpɪɹ. ðeɪ nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

"Mat" Perrin said, without understanding how he knew. The colors didn't appear. They never did in the wolf dream.

əz fulɪʃ ə kʌb əz jɝsɛlf?

As foolish a cub as yourself?

"meɪbi mɔɹ fulɪʃ."

"Maybe more foolish."

hɑpɝ smɛld ɪnkɹɛdʒələs, əz ɪf ənwɪlɪŋ tə bɪliv ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. kʌm, ðə wʊlf sɛnt. ɪts ɹɪtɝnd.

Hopper smelled incredulous, as if unwilling to believe that was possible. Come, the wolf sent. It has returned.

"wʌɾ əz - "

"What has - "

hɑpɝ vænɪʃt. pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd wɪð ə fɹaʊn. hi naʊ kəɾ izəli kætʃ ðə sɛn ʌv wɛɹ hɑpɝ hæd ɡɔn. ðeɪ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd, ən ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ vaɪəlɪt ɡlæs wɔl wɑz ðəɹ əɡɛn, slaɪsɪŋ ðə ɹoʊdweɪ ɪn hæf, ɪkstɛndɪŋ haɪ ɪn ði ɛɹ ən ɪndə ðə dɪstəns ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən.

Hopper vanished. Perrin followed with a frown. He now could easily catch the scent of where Hopper had gone. They appeared on the Jehannah Road, and that strange violet glass wall was there again, slicing the roadway in half, extending high in the air and into the distance in either direction.

pɛɹɪn wɔkt ʌp tə ə tʃɹi. ɪts bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz sim tʃɹæpt ɪn ðə ɡlæs, ɪmoʊbəl.

Perrin walked up to a tree. Its bare branches seemed trapped in the glass, immobile.

hɑpɝ peɪs nɪɹbaɪ. wɪv sin ðɪs θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ, hi sɛnt. lɔŋ, lɔŋ əɡoʊ. soʊ mɛni laɪvz əɡoʊ.

Hopper paced nearby. We have seen this thing before, he sent. Long, long ago. So many lives ago.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"What is it?"

ə θɪŋ ə mɛn.

A thing of men.

hɑpɝz sɛndɪŋ ɪnkluɾəd kənfjuzd ɪmədʒəz. flaɪɪŋ, ɡloʊɪŋ dɪsks. ɪmpɑsəbli tɔl stʃɹʌktʃɝz ə stil. θɪŋz fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz? hɑpɝ dɪdn ʌndɝstæn ðɛɹ juz ɛni mɔɹ ðən i ʌndɝstʊd ðə jus ʌv ə hɔɹs kɑɹɾ əɹ ə kændəl.

Hopper's sending included confused images. Flying, glowing discs. Impossibly tall structures of steel. Things from the Age of Legends? Hopper didn't understand their use any more than he understood the use of a horse cart or a candle.

pɛɹɪn lʊk daʊn ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. hi dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs sɛkʃən ʌv ɡildən; ɪt mʌs bi fɑɹðɝ təwɔɹd luɡɹd. ðə wɔl hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ə dɪfɹən pleɪs ðən ɪt hæd læs taɪm.

Perrin looked down the roadway. He didn't recognize this section of Ghealdan; it must be farther toward Lugard. The wall had appeared in a different place than it had last time.

ə θɔɾ əkɝɪŋ tə hɪm, pɛɹɪn muv daʊn ðə ɹoʊdweɪ ɪn ə fju dʒʌmpɪŋ bɝsts. ə hʌnʒɹəd ə peɪsɪz əweɪ, hi lʊk bæk ən kənfɝmd ɪz səspɪʃənz. ðət ɡlæs dɪdn meɪk ə wɔl, bʌɾ ən ɪnɔɹməs doʊm. tʃɹænslusənt, wɪð ə vaɪəlɪt tɪnt, ɪt sim tə ɪkstɛn fəɹ liɡz.

A thought occurring to him, Perrin moved down the roadway in a few jumping bursts. A hundred of paces away, he looked back and confirmed his suspicions. That glass didn't make a wall, but an enormous dome. Translucent, with a violet tint, it seemed to extend for leagues.

hɑpɝ muvd əɾ ə blɝ, kʌmɪŋ tə stæn bɪsaɪd hɪm. wi mʌst ɡoʊ.

Hopper moved at a blur, coming to stand beside him. We must go.

"hiz ɪn ðɛɹ, ɪzən hi?" pɛɹɪn æskt. hi ɹitʃt aʊt. oʊk dænsɝ, spɑɹks ən baʊnləs wɝ nɪɹ. əhɛd, ɪnsaɪd ðə doʊm. ðeɪ ɹɪspɑndɪd wɪð kwɪk, fɹæntɪk sɛndɪŋz, ət hʌn ən biɪŋ hʌntəd.

"He's in there, isn't he?" Perrin asked. He reached out. Oak Dancer, Sparks and Boundless were near. Ahead, inside the dome. They responded with quick, frantic sendings, at hunt and being hunted.

"waɪ doʊn ðeɪ fli?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Why don't they flee?" Perrin asked.

hɑpɝ sɛn kənfjuʒən.

Hopper sent confusion.

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðɛm," pɛɹɪn sɛd, wɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɔɹwɝd.

"I'm going to them," Perrin said, willing himself forward.

nʌθɪŋ hæpənd.

Nothing happened.

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə stæb ə pænɪk ɪn ɪz ɡʌt. wʌt wɑz ɹɔŋ? hi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɛn hɪmsɛlf tə ðə beɪs ə ðə doʊm.

Perrin felt a stab of panic in his gut. What was wrong? He tried again, this time trying to send himself to the base of the dome.

ɪt wɝkt. hi ɝaɪvd ɪn ən aɪɛblɪŋk, ðət ɡlæslaɪk sɝfəs ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ə klɪf feɪs bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ɪts ðɪs doʊm, hi θɔt. ɪts blɑkɪŋ mi. sʌɾənli, hi ʌndɝstʊd ðə tʃɹæp filɪŋ ðə wʊlvz hæd sɛnt. ðeɪ kʊdnt ɡɛɾ əweɪ.

It worked. He arrived in an eyeblink, that glasslike surface rising in a cliff face before him. It's this dome, he thought. It's blocking me. Suddenly, he understood the trapped feeling the wolves had sent. They couldn't get away.

wɑz ðət ðə pɝpəs ə ðɪs doʊm, ðɛn? tə tʃɹæp wʊlvz soʊ ðət sleɪɝ kəd kɪl ðɛm? pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə ðə sɝfəs ə ðə doʊm. hi kʊdn pæs ɪn baɪ ɪmædʒənɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ðɛɹ, bʌt pɝhæps i kəɾ i ɡɛt θɹu baɪ mɔɹ məndeɪn minz. hi ɹeɪzd ə hænd, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi dɪdnt noʊ wʌt tʌtʃɪŋ ðə sɝfəs wəd du.

Was that the purpose of this dome, then? To trap wolves so that Slayer could kill them? Perrin growled, stepping up to the surface of the dome. He couldn't pass in by imagining himself there, but perhaps he could he get through by more mundane means. He raised a hand, then hesitated. He didn't know what touching the surface would do.

ðə wʊlvz sɛn ɪmədʒəz ʌv ə mæn ɪn blæk ən lɛðɝ, wɪð ə hɑɹʃ laɪn feɪs ən ə smaɪl kɝlɪŋ ɑn ɪz lɪps əz i lɔntʃt æɹoʊz. hi smɛld ɹɔŋ, soʊ ɹɔŋ. hi ɔlsoʊ smɛld ə dɛd wʊlvz.

The wolves sent images of a man in black and leather, with a harsh lined face and a smile curling on his lips as he launched arrows. He smelled wrong, so wrong. He also smelled of dead wolves.

pɛɹɪn kʊdn liv əm ɪn ðɛɹ. noʊ mɔɹ ðən i kəd liv mæstɝ ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz tə ðə waɪtkloʊks. fjʊɹiəs ət sleɪɝ, hi tʌtʃt ðə sɝfəs ə ðə doʊm.

Perrin couldn't leave them in there. No more than he could leave Master Gill and the others to the Whitecloaks. Furious at Slayer, he touched the surface of the dome.

hɪz mʌsəlz sʌɾənli lɔst stʃɹɛŋkθ. ðeɪ fɛlt laɪk wɔɾɝ, hɪz lɛɡz əneɪbəl tə hoʊld ɪm ʌp. hi fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hɑɹd. hɪz fʊt wɑz stɪl tʌtʃɪŋ ðə doʊm - pæsɪŋ θɹu ɪt. ðə doʊm əpɪɹd tə hæv noʊ sʌbstəns.

His muscles suddenly lost strength. They felt like water, his legs unable to hold him up. He fell to the ground, hard. His foot was still touching the dome - passing through it. The dome appeared to have no substance.

hɪz lʌŋz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝkt; ɪnfleɪɾɪŋ ɪz tʃɛst wɑz tu dɪfəkəlt. pænɪkt, hi ɪmædʒən hɪmsɛlf ɛlswɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdnt wɝk. hi wɑz tʃɹæpt, əz ʃʊɹli əz ðə wʊlvz!

His lungs no longer worked; inflating his chest was too difficult. Panicked, he imagined himself elsewhere, but it didn't work. He was trapped, as surely as the wolves!

ə ɡɹeɪ-sɪlvɝ blɝ əpɪɹd nɛks tə hɪm. dʒɔz ɡɹæbd ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. əz hɑpɝ pʊld ɪm fɹi ʌv ðə vaɪəlɪt doʊm, pɛɹɪn ɪmiɾiətli fɛlt ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɹɪtɝn. hi ɡæsp fəɹ bɹɛθ.

A gray-silver blur appeared next to him. Jaws grabbed his shoulder. As Hopper pulled him free of the violet dome, Perrin immediately felt his strength return. He gasped for breath.

fulɪʃ kʌb, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

Foolish cub, Hopper sent.

"jud liv ðɛm?" pɛɹɪn sɛd, vɔɪs ɹæɡəd.

"You'd leave them?" Perrin said, voice ragged.

nɑt fulɪʃ tə dɪɡ ɪn ðə hoʊl. fulɪʃ fəɹ nɑt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi ɪn keɪs hɔɹnəts keɪm aʊt. hɑpɝ tɝn təwɔɹd ðə doʊm. hɛlp mi ɪf aɪ fɔl. hi pæɾəd fɔɹwɝd, ðən tʌtʃt ɪz noʊz tə ðə doʊm.

Not foolish to dig in the hole. Foolish for not waiting for me in case hornets came out. Hopper turned toward the dome. Help me if I fall. He padded forward, then touched his nose to the dome.

hɑpɝ stʌmbəld, bʌt ɹaɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf ən kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn sloʊli. ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, hi kəlæpst, bʌɾ ɪz tʃɛs kəntɪnjud tə muv.

Hopper stumbled, but righted himself and continued on slowly. On the other side, he collapsed, but his chest continued to move.

"haʊ dɪd jə də ɪt?" pɛɹɪn æskt, ɹaɪzɪŋ.

"How did you do it?" Perrin asked, rising.

aɪm mi. hɑpɝ əz i sɔ hɪmsɛlf - wɪtʃ wɑz aɪdɛntɪkəl tə hu hi wɑz. ɔlsoʊ sɛns ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ən stəbɪlɪɾi.

I am me. Hopper as he saw himself - which was identical to who he was. Also scents of strength and stability.

ðə tʃɹɪk, ɪt simd, wɑz tə bi ɪn kəmplit kəntʃɹoʊl ə hu jə wɝ. laɪk mɛni θɪŋz ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv wʌnz mɛntəl ɪmədʒ wɑz mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðən ðə sʌbstəns ə ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf.

The trick, it seemed, was to be in complete control of who you were. Like many things in the wolf dream, the strength of one's mental image was more powerful than the substance of the world itself.

kʌm, hɑpɝ sɛnt. bi stʃɹɔŋ, pæs θɹu.

Come, Hopper sent. Be strong, pass through.

"aɪ hæv ə bɛɾɝ aɪdiə," pɛɹɪn sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp. hi tʃɑɹdʒ fɔɹwɝɾ ət fjui spid. hi hɪt ðə vaɪəlɪt doʊm ən ɪmiɾiətli wɛn lɪmp, bʌɾ ɪz moʊmɛntəm kæɹiɾ ɪm tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd, wɛɹ i ɹoʊl tə ə stɑp. hi ɡɹoʊnd, ʃoʊldɝ hɝt, ɑɹm skɹeɪpt. fulɪʃ kʌb, hɑpɝ sɛnt. jə mʌs lɝn. "naʊ ɪzən ðə taɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ tə hɪz fit. "wi hæv tə hɛlp ði ʌðɝz."

"I have a better idea," Perrin said, standing up. He charged forward at fuII speed. He hit the violet dome and immediately went limp, but his momentum carried him to the other side, where he rolled to a stop. He groaned, shoulder hurt, arm scraped. Foolish cub, Hopper sent. You must learn. "Now isn't the time," Perrin said, climbing to his feet. "We have to help the others."

æɹoʊz ɪn ðə wɪnd, θɪk, blæk, dɛdli. ðə hʌntɝz læftɝ. ðə sɛn ʌv ə mæn u wɑz steɪl.

Arrows in the wind, thick, black, deadly. The hunter's laughter. The scent of a man who was stale.

ðə kɪlɝ wɑz hɪɹ. hɑpɝ ən pɛɹɪn ɹæn daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, ən pɛɹɪn faʊn ðəɾ i kəɾ ɪnkɹis ɪz spid wɪðɪn ðə doʊm. tɛntəɾɪvli, hi tʃɹaɪd dʒʌmpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd wɪð ə θɔt, ən ɪt wɝkt. bʌt wən i tʃɹaɪd tə sɛn hɪmsɛlf aʊtsaɪd, nʌθɪŋ hæpənd.

The killer was here. Hopper and Perrin ran down the road, and Perrin found that he could increase his speed within the dome. Tentatively, he tried jumping forward with a thought, and it worked. But when he tried to send himself outside, nothing happened.

soʊ ðə doʊm wɑz ə bæɹiɝ. wɪðɪn ɪt, hi kəd muv fɹili, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt muv tə ə pleɪs aʊtsaɪɾ ɪt baɪ ɪmædʒənɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɛlswɛɹ. hi hæd tə pæs ðə doʊmz wɔl fɪzɪkəli ɪf i wɑntəɾ aʊt.

So the dome was a barrier. Within it, he could move freely, but he could not move to a place outside it by imagining himself elsewhere. He had to pass the dome's wall physically if he wanted out.

oʊk dænsɝ, baʊnləs ən spɑɹks wɝ əhɛd. ən sleɪɝ, tu. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld - fɹæntɪk sɛndɪŋz flʌɾəd hɪm. dɑɹk wʊdz. sleɪɝ. hi sim soʊ tɔl tə ðə wʊlvz, ə dɑɹk mɑnstɝ wɪð ə feɪs tʃɪzəld əz ɪf fɹəm ɹɑk.

Oak Dancer, Boundless and Sparks were ahead. And Slayer, too. Perrin growled - frantic sendings flooded him. Dark woods. Slayer. He seemed so tall to the wolves, a dark monster with a face chiseled as if from rock.

blʌɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹæs. peɪn, æŋɡɝ, tɛɹɝ, kənfjuʒən. spɑɹks wɑz wundəd. ði ʌðɝ tu dʒʌmp bæk ən fɔɹθ, tɔntɪŋ ən dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ sleɪɝ waɪl spɑɹks kɹɔl təwɔɹd ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə ðə doʊm.

Blood on the grass. Pain, anger, terror, confusion. Sparks was wounded. The other two jumped back and forth, taunting and distracting Slayer while Sparks crawled toward the border of the dome.

kɛɹ, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ðɪs mæn hʌns wɛl. hi muvz ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə wʊlf, ðoʊ hiz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ.

Care, Young Bull, Hopper sent. This man hunts well. He moves almost like a wolf, though he is something wrong.

"aɪl dɪstʃɹæk hɪm. jə ɡɛt spɑɹks."

"I'll distract him. You get Sparks."

juv ɑɹmz. jə kæɹi. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə ðə sɛndɪŋ ðən ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs: hɑpɝz eɪdʒ ən ɪkspɪɹiəns, pɛɹɪn stɪl ə pʌp.

You have arms. You carry. There was more to the sending than that, of course: Hopper's age and experience, Perrin still a pup.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, bʌt dɪdn ɑɹɡju. hɑpɝ wɑz mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðən i wɑz. ðeɪ pɑɹɾəd, pɛɹɪn ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt fəɹ spɑɹks, faɪndɪŋ wɛɹ i wɑz - hɪɾən wɪðɪn ə pætʃ ə tʃɹiz - ən teɪkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf dɝɛkli ðɛɹ.

Perrin gritted his teeth, but didn't argue. Hopper was more experienced than he was. They parted, Perrin reaching out for Sparks, finding where he was - hidden within a patch of trees - and taking himself directly there.

ðə dɑɹk bɹaʊn wʊlf hæɾ ən æɹoʊ ɪn ɪz θaɪ, ən i wɑz wɪmpɝɪŋ sɔfli, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ blʌɾ əz i kɹɔld. pɛɹɪn nɛl kwɪkli ən pʊl ði æɹoʊ aʊt. ðə wʊlf kəntɪnjud tə wɪmpɝ, smɛlɪŋ fɹaɪɾənd. pɛɹɪn hɛl ði æɹoʊ ʌp. ɪt smɛld ivəl. dɪsɡʌstəd, hi tɔst ɪɾ əsaɪɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ðə wʊlf.

The dark brown wolf had an arrow in his thigh, and he was whimpering softly, trailing blood as he crawled. Perrin knelt quickly and pulled the arrow out. The wolf continued to whimper, smelling frightened. Perrin held the arrow up. It smelled evil. Disgusted, he tossed it aside and picked up the wolf.

sʌmθɪŋ kɹækəl nɪɹbaɪ, ən pɛɹɪn spʌn. baʊnləs lɛp bɪtwin tu tʃɹiz, smɛlɪŋ æŋkʃəs. ði ʌðɝ tu wʊlvz wɝ liɾɪŋ sleɪɝ əweɪ.

Something crackled nearby, and Perrin spun. Boundless leaped between two trees, smelling anxious. The other two wolves were leading Slayer away.

pɛɹɪn tɝn ən ɹæn təwɔɹd ðə doʊmz nɪɹəst ɛdʒ, kæɹiɪŋ spɑɹks. hi kʊdn lip dɝɛkli tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə doʊm kəz i dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ ɪt wɑz.

Perrin turned and ran toward the dome's nearest edge, carrying Sparks. He couldn't leap directly to the edge of the dome because he didn't know where it was.

hi bɝs fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ. ðə wʊlf ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz sim tə ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ əz ðeɪ lɛf ði æɹoʊ bɪhaɪnd. pɛɹɪn ɹæn mɔɹ kwɪkli, juzɪŋ ə spid ðət fɛlt ɹɛkləs, muvɪŋ hʌnʒɹədz ə peɪsɪz wɪð blɝɪŋ spid. ðə doʊm wɔl əpɹoʊtʃt, ən i pʊl tə ə stɑp.

He burst from the trees, heart thumping. The wolf in his arms seemed to grow stronger as they left the arrow behind. Perrin ran more quicly, using a speed that felt reckless, moving hundreds of paces with blurring speed. The dome wall approached, and he pulled to a stop.

sleɪɝ wɑz sʌɾənli ðɛɹ, stændɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɪm, baʊ dʒɹɔn. hi wɔɹ ə blæk kloʊk ðət bɪloʊɾ ɝaʊn hɪm; hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ smaɪlɪŋ, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ θʌndɝəs.

Slayer was suddenly there, standing before him, bow drawn. He wore a black cloak that billowed around him; he was no longer smiling, and his eyes were thunderous.

hi ɹilist. pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ən nɛvɝ sɔ wɛɹ ði æɹoʊ lændəd. hi əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɝst ɛntɝd ðə doʊm; hi ʃʊɾə ɡɔn ðəɹ fɝst. hi hɝl hɪmsɛlf θɹu ðə vaɪəlɪt doʊm, kəlæpsɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, sɛndɪŋ spɑɹks tʌmbəlɪŋ.

He released. Perrin shifted and never saw where the arrow landed. He appeared in the place where he'd first entered the dome; he should have gone there first. He hurled himself through the violet dome, collapsing on the other side, sending Sparks tumbling.

ðə wʊlf jɛlpt. pɛɹɪn hɪt hɑɹd.

The wolf yelped. Perrin hit hard.

jʌŋ bʊl! spɑɹks sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ə sleɪɝ, dɑɹk laɪk ə θʌndɝhɛd, stændɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə bæɹiɝ wɪð baʊ dʒɹɔn.

Young Bull! Sparks sent an image of Slayer, dark like a thunderhead, standing right inside the barrier with bow drawn.

pɛɹɪn dɪdn lʊk. hi ʃɪftəd, sɛndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡən-maʊnt. wʌns ðɛɹ, hi lɛp tə hɪz fit, æŋkʃəs, hæmɝ əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænd. ɡɹups ə nɪɹbaɪ wʊlvz sɛnt ɡɹiɾɪŋ.

Perrin didn't look. He shifted, sending himself to the slopes of Dragon-mount. Once there, he leaped to his feet, anxious, hammer appearing in his hand. Groups of nearby wolves sent greeting.

pɛɹɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm fəɹ ðə moʊmənt.

Perrin ignored them for the moment.

sleɪɝ dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ. æftɝ ə fju tɛns moʊməns, hɑpɝ əpɪɹd. "dɪd ði ʌðɝz ɡɛɾ əweɪ?"

Slayer did not follow. After a few tense moments, Hopper appeared. "Did the others get away?"

pɛɹɪn æskt.

Perrin asked.

ðeɪ ɑɹ fɹi, hi sɛnt. wɪspɝɝ ɪz dɛd. ðə sɛndɪŋ ʃoʊd ðə wʊlf -  fɹəm ðə vjupɔɪn ə ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə pæk - biɪŋ kɪl moʊməns æftɝ ðə doʊm əpɪɹd. spɑɹks hæd teɪkən ən æɹoʊ əz i nʌzəld əɾ əɹ saɪɾ ɪn pænɪk.

They are free, he sent. Whisperer is dead. The sending showed the wolf -  from the viewpoint of the others in the pack - being killed moments after the dome appeared. Sparks had taken an arrow as he nuzzled at her side in panic.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld. hi nɪɹli dʒʌmpt əweɪ tə kənfɹʌn sleɪɝ əɡɛn, bʌɾ ə kɑʃən fɹəm hɑpɝ stɑp hɪm. tu sun! jə mʌs lɝn!

Perrin growled. He nearly jumped away to confront Slayer again, but a caution from Hopper stopped him. Too soon! You must learn!

"ɪts nɑɾ oʊnli hɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ nid tə lʊk ət ði ɛɹiə ɝaʊn maɪ kæmp ən ðəɾ ə ðə waɪtkloʊks. sʌmθɪŋ smɛlz ɹɔŋ ðəɹ ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld. aɪ nid tə si ɪf sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɑd ðɛɹ."

"It's not only him," Perrin said. "I need to look at the area around my camp and that of the Whitecloaks. Something smells wrong there in the waking world. I need to see if something is odd there."

ɑd? hɑpɝ sɛn ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə doʊm.

Odd? Hopper sent the image of the dome.

"ɪɾ ɪz pɹɑbli ɹɪleɪɾɪd." ðə tu ɑɾətiz sim laɪkli tə bi mɔɹ ðən mɪɹ koʊɪnsɪɾəns.

"It is probably related." The two oddities seemed likely to be more than mere coincidence.

sɝtʃ ənʌðɝ taɪm. sleɪɝ ɪz tu stʃɹɔŋ fəɹ ju.

Search another time. Slayer is too strong for you.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ hæv tə feɪs ɪm ɪvɛntʃəwəli, hɑpɝ."

Perrin took a deep breath. "I have to face him eventually, Hopper."

nɑt naʊ.

Not now.

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn əɡɹid. "nɑt naʊ. naʊ wi pɹæktəs." hi tɝn tə ðə wʊlf. "æz wɪl də ɛvɹi naɪɾ əntɪl aɪm ɹɛɾi."

"No," Perrin agreed. "Not now. Now we practice." He turned to the wolf. "As we will do every night until I am ready."

ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz kɑt, nɛk slɪk wɪð swɛt. hæd sɑldɑiə ɔlweɪz bɪn ðɪs hɑɾ ən mʌɡi? hi wɪʃt fəɹ hoʊm, ðə kul oʊʃən bɹizɪz ə bændɑɹ ɛbən.

Rodel Ituralde rolled over in his cot, neck slick with sweat. Had Saldaea always been this hot and muggy? He wished for home, the cool ocean breezes of Bandar Eban.

θɪŋz fɛlt ɹɔŋ. waɪ hædn ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ətækt? ə hʌnʒɹəd pɑsəbɪləɾiz ɹæɾəld ɪn ɪz maɪnd. wɝ ðeɪ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ nu sidʒ ɛnʒənz?

Things felt wrong. Why hadn't the Shadowspawn attacked? A hundred possibilities rattled in his mind. Were they waiting for new siege engines?

wɝ ðeɪ skaʊɾɪŋ aʊt fɔɹəsts ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə bɪl ðɛm? əɹ wɝ ðɛɹ kɑm- mændɝz kɑntɛnt wɪð ə sidʒ? ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi wɑz sɝaʊndəd, bʌt ðəɹ hæd tə bi ɪnʌf tʃɹɑləks aʊt ðəɹ tə oʊvɝwɛlm ɪt naʊ.

Were they scouting out forests in order to build them? Or were their com- manders content with a siege? The entire city was surrounded, but there had to be enough Trollocs out there to overwhelm it now.

ðeɪ hæd teɪkən tə biɾɪŋ dʒɹʌmz. ɔl aʊɝz. θʌmp, θʌmp, θʌmp. stɛɾi, laɪk ðə hɑɹtbiɾ ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs ænəməl, ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɪtsɛlf, kɔɪlɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi.

They had taken to beating drums. All hours. Thump, thump, thump. Steady, like the heartbeat of an enormous animal, the Great Serpent itself, coiling around the city.
