dɔn wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃaɪn aʊtsaɪd. hi hædn tɝn ɪn əntɪl wɛl æftɝ mɪdnaɪt. dɝəm - hu kəmændəd ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑtʃ - hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi nɑt bi dɪstɝbd əntɪl nun. hɪz tɛnt wɑz ɪn ə ʃæɾoʊd ælkoʊv ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. hi hæd wɑntəd tə bi kloʊs tə ðə wɔl, ən hæd ɹəfjuzd ə bɛd.

Dawn was beginning to shine outside. He hadn't turned in until well after midnight. Durhem - who commanded the morning watch - had ordered that Ituralde not be disturbed until noon. His tent was in a shadowed alcove of the courtyard. He had wanted to be close to the wall, and had refused a bed.

ðət hæd bɪn fulɪʃ. ðoʊ ə kɑt hæd bɪn faɪn fəɹ ɪm ɪn pɹiviəs jɪɹz, hi wɑzn əz jʌŋ əz hid wʌns bɪn. təmɑɹoʊ, hid muv.

That had been foolish. Though a cot had been fine for him in previous years, he wasn't as young as he'd once been. Tomorrow, he'd move.

naʊ, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf, slip.

Now, he told himself, sleep.

ɪt wɑzn ðəɾ izi. ði ækjəzeɪʃən ðəɾ i wɑz dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn lɛft ɪm ənsɛɾəld. ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, hid bɪn faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪz kɪŋ, sʌmwʌn hid bɪlivd ɪn. naʊ hi wɑz faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə fɔɹən læn fəɹ ə mæn hid mɛɾ oʊnli wʌns. ɔl kəz ʌv ə ɡʌt filɪŋ.

It wasn't that easy. The accusation that he was Dragonsworn left him unsettled. In Arad Doman, he'd been fighting for his king, someone he'd believed in. Now he was fighting in a foreign land for a man he'd met only once. All because of a gut feeling.

laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑt. swɛt ɹæn daʊn ɪz tʃiks, meɪkɪŋ ɪz nɛk ɪtʃ. ɪt ʃʊdn bi ðɪs hɑt soʊ ɝli ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ɪt wɑznt nætʃɹəl. ðoʊz bɝnɪŋ dʒɹʌmz, stɪl paʊndɪŋ.

Light, but it was hot. Sweat ran down his cheeks, making his neck itch. It shouldn't be this hot so early in the morning. It wasn't natural. Those burning drums, still pounding.

hi saɪd, klaɪmɪŋ ɔf ɪz swɛt-dæmpən kɑt. hɪz lɛɡ ætʃt. ɪt hæd fəɹ deɪz naʊ.

He sighed, climbing off his sweat-dampened cot. His leg ached. It had for days now.

jəɹ ən oʊl mæn, ɹoʊɾəl, hi θɔt, stʃɹɪpɪŋ ɔf ɪz swɛɾi smɔlkloʊðz ən ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt səm fɹɛʃli wɑʃt wʌnz. hi stʌft ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz ɪndə ni-haɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ buts. ə sɪmpəl waɪt ʃɝt wɪð blæk bʌɾənz wɛn ɑn nɛkst, ən ðən ɪz ɡɹeɪ koʊt, bʌtoʊnɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp tə ðə kɑlɝ.

You're an old man, Rodel, he thought, stripping off his sweaty smallclothes and getting out some freshly washed ones. He stuffed his trousers into knee-high riding boots. A simple white shirt with black buttons went on next, and then his gray coat, buttoning straight up to the collar.

hi wɑz stʃɹæpɪŋ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd wən i hɝd hɝid fʊtstɛps aʊtsaɪd, fɑloʊd baɪ wɪspɝz.

He was strapping on his sword when he heard hurried footsteps outside, followed by whispers.

ðət kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɡɹu hiɾəd, ən i stɛpt aʊtsaɪd dʒʌst əz sʌmwʌn sɛd, "lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi wɪl wɪʃ tə noʊ!"

That conversation grew heated, and he stepped outside just as someone said, "Lord Ituralde will wish to know!"

noʊ wʌt?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt. ə mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪ wɑz ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð ɪz ɡɑɹdz. ɔl θɹi tɝn təwɔɹɾ ɪm ʃipɪʃli.

Know what?" Ituralde asked. A messenger boy was arguing with his guards. All three turned toward him sheepishly.

"aɪm sɑɹi, maɪ lɔɹd," kənəl sɛd. "wi wɝ ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə lɛt jə slip."

"I'm sorry, my Lord," Connel said. "We were instructed to let you sleep."

ə mæn u kən slip ɪn ðɪs hit mʌs bi hæf-lɪzɝd, kənəl," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "læd, wʌts ðə wɝd?"

A man who can sleep in this heat must be half-lizard, Connel," Ituralde said. "Lad, what's the word?"

kæptən joʊli ɪz ɑn ðə wɔl, sɝ," ðə juθ sɛd. ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə jʌŋ mæn - hid bɪn wɪð ɪm fɹəm nɪɹ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðɪs kæmpeɪn. "hi sɛd jə ʃəd kʌm."

Captain Yoeli is on the wall, sir," the youth said. Ituralde recognized the young man - he'd been with him from near the beginning of this campaign. "He said you should come."

ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd. hi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn kənəlz ɑɹm. "θæŋk jə fəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ mi, oʊl fɹɛnd, bʌt ðiz boʊnz ɑɹən soʊ fɹeɪl əz jə θɪŋk."

Ituralde nodded. He laid a hand on Connel's arm. "Thank you for watching me, old friend, but these bones aren't so frail as you think."

kənəl nɑɾəd, blʌʃɪŋ. ðə ɡɑɹd fɛl ɪndə pleɪs bɪhaɪn əz ɪɾɝɑldi kɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ðə sʌn hæd ɹɪzən. mɛni ʌv ɪz tʃɹups wɝ ʌp. tu mɛni. hi wɑzn ði oʊnli wʌn hævɪŋ dɪfəkəlti slipɪŋ.

Connel nodded, blushing. The guard fell into place behind as Ituralde crossed the courtyard. The sun had risen. Many of his troops were up. Too many. He wasn't the only one having difficulty sleeping.

ətɑp ðə wɔl, hi wɑz ɡɹiɾəd baɪ ə dɪshɑɹɾənɪŋ saɪt. ɑn ðə daɪɪŋ lænd, θaʊzən əpɑn θaʊzənz ə tʃɹɑləks kæmpt, bɝnɪŋ faɪɝz. ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdn laɪk tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wɛɹ ðə wʊd fəɹ ðoʊz faɪɝz keɪm fɹʌm. hoʊpfəli ɔl ə ðə nɪɹbaɪ hoʊmstɛɾɝz ən vɪlɪdʒɝz hæd hiɾəd ðə kɔl tə ɪvækjəeɪt.

Atop the wall, he was greeted by a disheartening sight. On the dying land, thousand upon thousands of Trollocs camped, burning fires. Ituralde didn't like to think about where the wood for those fires came from. Hopefully all of the nearby homesteaders and villagers had heeded the call to evacuate.

joʊli stʊd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə kɹɛnəleɪɾəd stoʊn ə ðə wɔl, nɛks tə ə mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt. dip bɑɾɝ wɑz sinjɝ əmʌŋ ði æʃəmən hum ælθɹ hæd ɡɪvən hɪm, wʌn ʌv oʊnli θɹi hu wɔɹ boʊθ ðə dʒɹæɡən ən ðə sɔɹd pɪnz ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ. ði ændɔɝən mæn hæɾ ə flæt feɪs ən blæk hɛɹ ðəɾ i wɔɹ lɔŋ. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd səmtaɪmz hɝd səm ə ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn mʌmbəlɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt nɑt dip. hi sim fʊli ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl.

Yoeli stood gripping the crenelated stone of the wall, next to a man in a black coat. Deepe Bhadar was senior among the Asha'man whom al'Thor had given him, one of only three who wore both the Dragon and the sword pins on his collar. The Andoran man had a flat face and black hair that he wore long. Ituralde had sometimes heard some of the black-coated men mumbling to themselves, but not Deepe. He seemed fully in control.

joʊli kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ ət ði æʃəmən; ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdn fil kʌmftəɹbəl. wɪð mɛn u kəd tʃænəl iðɝ. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ən ɛksələn tul, ən ðeɪ hædn feɪl hɪm. hi pɹəfɝd tə lɛɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns, ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹumɝ, ɹul hɪm.

Yoeli kept glancing at the Asha'man; Ituralde didn't feel comfortable. with men who could channel either. But they were an excellent tool, and they hadn't failed him. He preferred to let experience, instead of rumor, rule him.

"lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi," dip sɛd. ði æʃəmən nɛvɝ səluɾəd ɪɾɝɑldi, dʒʌst ælθɹ.

"Lord Ituralde," Deepe said. The Asha'man never saluted Ituralde, just al'Thor.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt, skænɪŋ ðə hɔɹdz ə tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ dɪdn sim tə hæv tʃeɪnʒd sɪns hid bɛɾəd daʊn.

"What is it?" Ituralde asked, scanning the hordes of Trollocs. They didn't seem to have changed since he'd bedded down.

"jɔɹ mæn kleɪmz tə bi eɪbəl tɔɪw sʌmθɪŋ," joʊli sɛd. "aʊt ðɛɹ."

"Your man claims to be able toyW something," Yoeli said. "Out there."

"ðeɪ hæv tʃænlɝz, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi," dip sɛd. "aɪ səspɛkt ət list sɪks, pɝhæps mɔɹ. mɛn, sɪns aɪ kən fil ðə paʊɝ ðəɹ wildɪŋ, duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ paʊɝfəl. ɪf aɪ skwɪn ət ðə fɑɹ kæmps, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən səmtaɪmz si wivz, bʌɾ ɪt meɪ bi maɪ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən."

"They have channelers, Lord Ituralde," Deepe said. "I suspect at least six, perhaps more. Men, since I can feel the Power they're wielding, doing something powerful. If I squint at the far camps, I think I can sometimes see weaves, but it may be my imagination."

ɪɾɝɑldi kɝst. "ðæts wʌt ðeɪv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ."

Ituralde cursed. "That's what they've been waiting for."

"wʌt?" joʊli æskt.

"What?" Yoeli asked.

"wɪð æʃəmən ə ðɛɹ oʊn - "

"With Asha'man of their own - "

"ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ æʃəmən," dip sɛd fɝvənli.

"They are not Asha'man," Deepe said fervently.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn. wɪð tʃænlɝz ə ðɛɹ oʊn, ðeɪ kən tɛɹ ðɪs wɔl daʊn izəli əz nɑkɪŋ oʊvɝ ə paɪl ə blɑks, joʊli. ðət si ʌv tʃɹɑləks wɪl sɝdʒ ɪn ən fɪl jəɹ stʃɹits."

"All right, then. With channelers of their own, they can tear this wall down easily as knocking over a pile of blocks, Yoeli. That sea of Trollocs will surge in and fill your streets."

"nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪ stænd," dip sɛd.

"Not so long as I stand," Deepe said.

"aɪ laɪk dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɪn ə soʊlʒɝ, dip," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "bʌt jə lʊk əz ɪɡzɔstəɾ əz aɪ fil."

"I like determination in a soldier, Deepe," Ituralde said, "but you look as exhausted as I feel."

dip ʃɑɾ ɪm ə ɡlɛɹ. hɪz aɪz wɝ ɹɛd fɹəm læk ə slip, ən i klɛntʃt ɪz tiθ, ðə mʌsəlz ɪn ɪz nɛk ən feɪs tɛns. hi mɛɾ ɪɾɝəl- di-ɛs aɪz, ðən tʊk ə lɔŋ, fɔɹs bɹɛθ.

Deepe shot him a glare. His eyes were red from lack of sleep, and he clenched his teeth, the muscles in his neck and face tense. He met Itural- de-s eyes, then took a long, forced breath.

"ju ɑɹ kɝɛkt," dip sɛd. "bʌt niðɝ ʌv əs kən də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt." hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hænd, duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi kʊdn si. ə flæʃ ə ɹɛd laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hænd - ðə sɪɡnəl i juz tə dʒɹɔ ði ʌðɝz tə hɪm. "pɹipɛɹ jəɹ mɛn, dʒɛnɝəl, kæptən. ɪɾəl nɑt bi lɔŋ. ðeɪ kænɑt kəntɪnju tə hoʊl ðət kaɪndə paʊɝ wɪθaʊt . . .

"You are correct," Deepe said. "But neither of us can do anything about that." He raised his hand, doing something that Ituralde couldn't see. A flash of red light appeared over his hand - the signal he used to draw the others to him. "Prepare your men, General, Captain. It will not be long. They cannot continue to hold that kind of Power without . . .

kɑnsəkwɛnsəz."

consequences."

joʊli nɑɾəd, ðən hɝiɾ əweɪ. ɪɾɝɑldi tʊk dips ɑɹm, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz ətɛnʃən.

Yoeli nodded, then hurried away. Ituralde took Deepe's arm, drawing his attention.

"ju æʃəmən ɑɹ tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt ə ɹisɔɹs tə luz," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛn əs hɪɹ tə hɛlp, nɑt tə daɪ. ɪf ðɪs sɪɾi fɔlz, aɪ wɑn jə tə teɪk ði ʌðɝz ən wʌtɛvɝ wundəd jə kən ən ɡɛɾ aʊt. dʒju ʌndɝstænd, soʊlʒɝ?"

"You Asha'man are too important a resource to lose," Ituralde said. "The Dragon sent us here to help, not to die. If this city falls, I want you to take the others and whatever wounded you can and get out. Do you understand, soldier?"

"mɛni ʌv maɪ mɛn wɪl nɑt laɪk ðɪs."

"Many of my men will not like this."

"bʌt jə noʊ ɪts fəɹ ðə bɛst," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "doʊn ju?"

"But you know it is for the best," Ituralde said. "Don't you?"

dip hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "jɛs. jə ɑɹ kɝɛkt, əz jə soʊ ɔfən ɑɹ. əl ɡɛɾ əm aʊt." hi spoʊk ɪn ə loʊɝ vɔɪs. "ðɪs ɪz ə hoʊpləs ɹɪzɪstəns, maɪ lɔɹd. wʌtɛvɝ ɪz hæpənɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ, ɪɾəl bi dɛdli. ɪt ɡɔlz mi tə sədʒɛst ɪt . . . bʌt wʌt juv sɛɾ əbaʊt maɪ æʃəmən əplaɪz tə jəɹ soʊlʒɝz əz wɛl. lɛɾ əs fli." hi sɛd ðə wɝd "fli" wɪð bɪɾɝnəs.

Deepe hesitated. "Yes. You are correct, as you so often are. I will get them out." He spoke in a lower voice. "This is a hopeless resistance, my Lord. Whatever is happening out there, it will be deadly. It galls me to suggest it . . . but what you have said about my Asha'man applies to your soldiers as well. Let us flee." He said the word "flee" with bitterness.

"ðə sɑldəiənz wʊdn liv wɪð ʌs."

"The Saldaeans wouldn't leave with us."

"aɪ noʊ."

"I know."

ɪɾɝɑldi kənsɪɾɝd ɪt. faɪnəli, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɛvɹi deɪ wi dɪleɪ ʌp hɪɹ kips ðiz mɑnstɝz əweɪ fɹəm maɪ hoʊmlæn ə deɪ lɔŋɡɝ. noʊ, aɪ kænɑt ɡoʊ, dip. ðɪs ɪz stɪl ðə bɛs pleɪs tə faɪt. juv sin haʊ fɔɹɾəfaɪd ðoʊz bɪldɪŋz ɑɹ; wi kən hoʊld ɪnsaɪd fəɹ ə fju deɪz, splɪɾ əpɑɹt, kip ði ɑɹmi bɪzi."

Ituralde considered it. Finally, he shook his head. "Every day we delay up here keeps these monsters away from my homeland a day longer. No, I cannot go, Deepe. This is still the best place to fight. You've seen how fortified those buildings are; we can hold inside for a few days, split apart, keep the army busy."

"ðɛn maɪ æʃəmən kəd steɪ ən hɛlp."

"Then my Asha'man could stay and help."

"ju hæv jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz, sʌn. jə fɑloʊ ðɛm. ʌndɝstænd?"

"You have your orders, son. You follow them. Understand?"

dip snæpt ɪz dʒɔ ʃʌt, ðən nɑɾəd kɝtli. "aɪ wɪl teɪk - "

Deep snapped his jaw shut, then nodded curtly. "I will take - "

ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdn hɪɹ ðə ɹɛst. ən ɪksploʊʒən hɪt.

Ituralde didn't hear the rest. An explosion hit.

hi dɪdn fil ɪɾ ɝaɪv. hi wɑz stændɪŋ wɪð dip wʌn moʊmənt, ðən ɹaʊn hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə flɔɹ ə ðə wɔl wɔk, ðə wɝl stʃɹeɪnʒli saɪlən ɝaʊn hɪm. hɪz hɛd skɹimd wɪð peɪn ən i kɔft, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə tʃɹɛm- bəlɪŋ hæn tə faɪn ɪz feɪs bliɾɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɹaɪɾ aɪ;

He didn't feel it arrive. He was standing with Deepe one moment, then round himself on the floor of the wall walk, the world strangely silent around him. His head screamed with pain and he coughed, raising a trem- bling hand to find his face bleeding. There was something in his right eye;

ɪt sɪɹd wɪð peɪn wən i blɪŋkt. waɪ wɑz ɛvɹiθɪŋ soʊ kwaɪət?

it seared with pain when he blinked. Why was everything so quiet?

hi ɹoʊld oʊvɝ, kɑfɪŋ əɡɛn, ɹaɪɾ aɪ skwizd ʃʌt, ði ʌðɝ wɔɾɝɪŋ. ðə wɔl ɛndəɾ ə fju ɪntʃəz əweɪ fɹəm hɪm.

He rolled over, coughing again, right eye squeezed shut, the other watering. The wall ended a few inches away from him.

hi ɡæspt. ən ɪnɔɹməs tʃʌŋk ə ðə nɔɹðɝn wɔl wɑz sɪmpli ɡɔn.

He gasped. An enormous chunk of the northern wall was simply gone.

hi ɡɹoʊnd, lʊkɪŋ bæk ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən. dip hæd bɪn stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm . . .

He groaned, looking back in the other direction. Deepe had been standing beside him . . .

hi faʊn ði æʃəmən laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔl wɔk nɪɹbaɪ, hɛd bliɾɪŋ. hɪz ɹaɪt lɛɡ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə ɹæɡəd ɹɪp ə flɛʃ ən bɹoʊkən boʊn əbʌv wɛɹ ðə ni ʃəɾ əv bɪn. ɪɾɝɑldi kɝst ən stʌmbəl fɔɹwɝd, dʒɹɔɹp-pɪŋ tə hɪz niz bɪsaɪd ðə mæn. blʌd wɑz pulɪŋ bɪniθ dip bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl twɪtʃɪŋ. əlaɪv.

He found the Ashaman lying on the wall walk nearby, head bleeding. His right leg ended in a ragged rip of flesh and broken bone above where the knee should have been. Ituralde cursed and stumbled forward, drorp-ping to his knees beside the man. Blood was pooling beneath Deepe but he was still twitching. Alive.

aɪ nid tə saʊn ði əlɑɹm . . .

I need to sound the alarm . . .

əlɑɹm? ðəɾ ɪksploʊʒən wʊɾə bɪn əlɑɹm ɪnʌf. ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔl, bɪldɪŋz wɝ dɪmɑlɪʃt, kɹʌʃt baɪ stoʊnz flaɪɪŋ ɪn ə spɹeɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðə hoʊl. aʊtsaɪd, tʃɹɑləks wɝ ləpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, kæɹiɪŋ ɹæfs tə kɹɔs ðə moʊt.

Alarm? That explosion would have been alarm enough. Inside the wall, buildings were demolished, crushed by stones flying in a spray away from the hole. Outside, Trollocs were loping forward, carrying rafts to cross the moat.

ɪɾɝɑldi pʊl ði æʃəmənz bɛlt ɔf ən juzd ɪt tə baɪn ɪz θaɪ. ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd θɪŋk tə du.

Ituralde pulled the Asha'man's belt off and used it to bind his thigh. It was all he could think to do.

hɪz hɛd wɑz stɪl θɹɑbɪŋ fɹəm ði ɪksploʊʒən.

His head was still throbbing from the explosion.

ðə sɪɾi ɪz lɔst. . . laɪt! ɪts lɔst, dʒʌs laɪk ðæt.

The city is lost. . . Light! It's lost, just like that.

hænz wɝ hɛlpɪŋ ɪm ʌp. deɪzədli hi ɡlænst əbaʊt. kənəl; hid sɝvaɪv ðə blæst, ðoʊ hɪz koʊt wɑz tɔɹn tə ʃɹɛdz. hi pʊld ɪɾɝɑldi əweɪ waɪl ə pɛɹ ə soʊlʒɝz tʊk dip.

Hands were helping him up. Dazedly he glanced about. Connel; he'd survived the blast, though his coat was torn to shreds. He pulled Ituralde away while a pair of soldiers took Deepe.

ðə nɛks mɪnəts wɝ ə blɝ. ɪɾɝɑldi stʌmbəl daʊn ðə stɛɹz fɹəm ðə wɔl, nɪɹli pɪtʃɪŋ hɛdfɝs fɪftin fiɾ ɑntu ðə kɑbəlz. oʊnli kɑn-nɛlz hænz kɛpt ɪm fɹəm fɔlɪŋ. ən ðən ... ə tɛnt?

The next minutes were a blur. Ituralde stumbled down the stairs from the wall, nearly pitching headfirst fifteen feet onto the cobbles. Only Con-nel's hands kept him from falling. And then ... a tent?

ə lɑɹdʒ oʊpən-saɪɾəd tɛnt? ɪɾɝɑldi blɪŋkt. ə bæɾəlfild ʃəd nɑt bi soʊ kwaɪət.

A large open-sided tent? Ituralde blinked. A battlefield should not be so quiet.

aɪsi koʊlnəs wɑʃt oʊvɝ hɪm. hi skɹimd. saʊnz əsɔltɪɾ ɪz ɪɹz ən maɪnd. skɹimz, ɹɑk bɹeɪkɪŋ, tʃɹʌmpəts saʊndɪŋ, dʒɹʌmz θɹɑbɪŋ. mɛn daɪɪŋ. ɪɾ ɔl hɪɾ ɪm ət wʌns, əz ɪf plʌɡz hæd bɪn jæŋk fɹəm ɪz ɪɹz.

Icy coldness washed over him. He screamed. Sounds assaulted his ears and mind. Screams, rock breaking, trumpets sounding, drums throbbing. Men dying. It all hit him at once, as if plugs had been yanked from his ears.

hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf, ɡæspɪŋ. hi wɑz ɪn ðə sɪk tɛnt. ænteɪl - ðə kwaɪət, θɪn-hɛɹɾ æʃəmən -  stʊɾ əbʌv hɪm. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪɾɝɑldi fɛlt ɪɡzɔstəd! tu lɪɾəl slip mɪkst wɪð ðə stʃɹeɪn ə biɪŋ hild. əz ðə saʊnz ə bæɾəl kənsum hɪm, hi faʊn ɪz aɪlɪdz tʃɹɛtʃɝəsli hɛvi.

He shook himself, gasping. He was in the sick tent. Antail - the quiet, thin-haired Ashaman -  stood above him. Light, but Ituralde felt exhausted! Too little sleep mixed with the strain of being Healed. As the sounds of battle consumed him, he found his eyelids treacherously heavy.

"lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi," ænteɪl sɛd, "aɪ hæv ə wiv ðət wɪl nɑt meɪk jə wɛl, bʌɾ ɪɾəl meɪk jə θɪŋk jə ɑɹ wɛl. ɪt kəd bi hɑɹmfəl tə ju. dʒju wɑn mi tə pɹəsid?"

"Lord Ituralde," Antail said, "I have a weave that will not make you well, but it will make you think you are well. It could be harmful to you. Do you want me to proceed?"

"aɪ . . ." ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. ðə wɝd keɪm aʊɾ əz ə mʌmbəl. "ɪt . . ."

"I . . ." Ituralde said. The word came out as a mumble. "It . . ."

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," ænteɪl mʌɾɝd. hi ɹitʃt fɔɹwɝd. ənʌðɝ weɪv ə paʊɝ wɑʃt θɹu ɪɾɝɑldi. ɪt wɑz laɪk ə bɹum swipɪŋ θɹu hɪm, pʊʃɪŋ əweɪ ɔl ə ðə fətiɡ ən kənfjuʒən, ɹɪstɔɹɪŋ ɪz sɛnsɪz ən meɪkɪŋ ɪm fil əz ɪf hid hæɾ ə pɝfək naɪts ɹɛst. hɪz ɹaɪɾ aɪ dɪdn hɝɾ ɛnimɔɹ.

"Blood and bloody ashes," Antail muttered. He reached forward. Another wave of Power washed through Ituralde. It was like a broom sweeping through him, pushing away all of the fatigue and confusion, restoring his senses and making him feel as if he'd had a perfect night's rest. His right eye didn't hurt anymore.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ lɪŋɡɝɪŋ, dip daʊn, ən ɪɡzɔstʃən ɪn ɪz boʊnz.

There was something lingering, deep down, an exhaustion in his bones.

hi kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðæt. hi sæɾ ʌp, bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt, ðən lʊk tə æn- teɪl. "naʊθəɾ ɪz ə jusfəl wiv, sʌn. jə ʃʊɾə toʊl mi jə kəd də ðɪs!"

He could ignore that. He sat up, breathed in and out, then looked to An- tail. "Nowthat is a useful weave, son. You should have told me you could do this!"

"ɪts deɪnʒɝəs," ænteɪl ɹɪpiɾɪd. "mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən ðə wɪmən ɛs vɝʒən aɪm toʊld. ɪn səm weɪz mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv. jəɹ tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ əlɝtnəs naʊ fəɹ mɔɹ pɹoʊfaʊn ɪɡzɔstʃən leɪɾɝ ɑn."

"It's dangerous," Antail repeated. "More dangerous than the women s version I'm told. In some ways more effective. You're trading alertness now for more profound exhaustion later on."

"leɪɾɝ ɑn, wi woʊn bi ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə sɪɾi ðəɾ ɪz fɔlɪŋ tə ðə tʃɹoʊl-lɑks. laɪt wɪlɪŋ, ət list. dip?"

"Later on, we won't be in the middle of a city that is falling to the Trol-locs. Light willing, at least. Deepe?"

"aɪ sɔ tə hɪm fɝst," ænteɪl sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ði æʃəmən laɪɪŋ ɑn ə nɪɹbaɪ kɑt, hɪz kloʊðɪŋ sɪŋʒd ən ɪz feɪs blʌɾid. hɪz ɹaɪt lɛɡ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə hil stʌmp, ən i əpɪɹd tə bi bɹiðɪŋ, ðoʊ ʌnkɑnʃəs.

"I saw to him first," Antail said, gesturing to the Asha'man lying on a nearby cot, his clothing singed and his face bloodied. His right leg ended in a healed stump, and he appeared to be breathing, though unconscious.

"kənəl!" ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

"Connel!" Ituralde said.

"maɪ lɔɹd," ðə soʊlʒɝ sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp. hid faʊn ə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz tə ækt əz ə pɝsənəl ɡɑɹd.

"My Lord," the soldier said, stepping up. He'd found a squad of soldiers to act as a personal guard.

"lɛts ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt ðɪs mɛs," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. hi ɹæn aʊɾ ə ðə sɪk tɛnt, təwɔɹd kɝdɑmɔɹə pæləs.

"Let's investigate this mess," Ituralde said. He ran out of the sick tent, toward Cordamora Palace.

ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɪn keɪɑs, ɡɹups ə sɑldəiənz ən dəmɑni ɹʌʃɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. kənəl, ʃoʊɪŋ fɔɹsaɪt, sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ tə faɪn joʊli.

The city was in chaos, groups of Saldaeans and Domani rushing this way and that. Connel, showing foresight, sent a messenger to find Yoeli.

ðə pæləs stʊd nɪɹbaɪ, dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə fɹʌnt ɡeɪt. ɪts wɔl hæd bɪn dæmədʒd ɪn ðə blæst, bʌt ðə bɪldɪŋ stɪl lʊk heɪl. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd bɪn juzɪŋ ɪɾ əz ə kəmæn poʊst. mɛn wəɾ ɪkspɛk tə faɪn ɪm hɪɹ. ðeɪ ɹæn ɪnsaɪd, kənəl kæɹiɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldiz sɔɹd - ðə bɛl hæd bɪn kʌt fɹi ət səm pɔɪnt.

The palace stood nearby, just before the front gate. Its wall had been damaged in the blast, but the building still looked hale. Ituralde had been using it as a command post. Men would expect to find him here. They ran inside, Connel carrying Ituralde's sword - the belt had been cut free at some point.

ðeɪ klaɪm tə ðə θɝd flɔɹ, ðən ɹæn aʊɾ ɑntu ə bælkəni ðət sɝveɪd ði ɛɹiə bɹoʊkən baɪ ðə blæst.

They climbed to the third floor, then ran out onto a balcony that surveyed the area broken by the blast.

əz hiɾ ɝɪdʒənəli fɪɹd, ðə sɪɾi wɑz lɔst. ðə swɑθ ə bɹoʊkən wɔl wɑz biɪŋ dɪfɛndəd baɪ ə heɪstəli əsɛmbəl dʒʌmbəl ə dɪfɛndɝz. ə maʊntɪŋ taɪɾ ə tʃɹɑləks wɝ θɹoʊɪŋ daʊn ɹæfs ɑn ðə moʊt, səm bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə sɝdʒ fɔɹwɝd, fɑloʊd baɪ feɪdz. mɛn ɹæn θɹu ðə stʃɹits, dɪsɔɹiɛntɪd.

As he'd originally feared, the city was lost. The swath of broken wall was being defended by a hastily assembled jumble of defenders. A mounting tide of Trollocs were throwing down rafts on the moat, some beginning to surge forward, followed by Fades. Men ran through the streets, disoriented.

ɪf hid hæd mɔɹ taɪm tə pɹipɛɹ, hi kəɾ əv hɛld, əz hid toʊl dip. nɑt naʊ. laɪt, bʌt ðɪs dɪfɛns əz bɪn wʌn dɪzæstɝ æftɝ ənʌðɝ.

If he'd had more time to prepare, he could have held, as he'd told Deepe. Not now. Light, but this defense has been one disaster after another.

ɡæðɝ ði æʃəmən," ɪɾɝɑldi ɔɹɾɝd. "æn ɛni ʌv maɪ ɔfəsɝz jə kən faɪnd. wɪl ɔɹɡənaɪz ðə mɛn ɪndə ə ɹitʃɹit θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz."

Gather the Asha'man," Ituralde ordered. "And any of my officers you can find. We will organize the men into a retreat through gateways."

jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," kənəl sɛd.

Yes, my Lord," Connel said.

"ɪɾɝɑldi, noʊ!" joʊli bɝst aʊɾ ɑntu ðə bælkəni, junəfɔɹm dɝɾid ən ɹɪpt.

"Ituralde, no!" Yoeli burst out onto the balcony, uniform dirtied and ripped.

"ju sɝvaɪvd," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, ɹɪlivd. "ɛksələnt. mæn, jəɹ sɪɾi ɪz lɔst. ɪm sɑɹi. bɹɪŋ jəɹ mɛn wɪð əs ən wi kən - "

"You survived," Ituralde said, relieved. "Excellent. Man, your city is lost. I'm sorry. Bring your men with us and we can - "

"lʊk!" joʊli sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldi tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bælkəni, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ði ist. ə θɪk kɑləm ə smoʊk ɹoʊz ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ə vɪlədʒ ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd bɝnd?

"Look!" Yoeli said, pulling Ituralde to the side of the balcony, pointing to the east. A thick column of smoke rose in the distance. A village the Trollocs had burned?

"ðə wɑtʃfaɪɝ," joʊli kəntɪnjud. "maɪ sɪstɝ əz sin eɪd kʌmɪŋ! wi mʌst stæn əntɪl ðeɪ ɝaɪv."

"The watchfire," Yoeli continued. "My sister has seen aid coming! We must stand until they arrive."

ɪɾɝɑldi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "joʊli," hi sɛd sɔfli, "ɪf ə fɔɹs əz kʌm, ɪt kæn bi lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə stɑp ðɪs hɔɹɾ ə tʃɹɑləks. ən ðæts əsumɪŋ ɪts nɑɾ ə ɹuz. ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn əv pɹuvən klɛvɝ ɪn ðə pæst."

Ituralde hesitated. "Yoeli," he said softly, "if a force has come, it can't be large enough to stop this horde of Trollocs. And that's assuming it's not a ruse. The Shadowspawn have proven clever in the past."

"ɡɪv əs ə fju aʊɝz," joʊli sɛd. "hoʊl ðə sɪɾi wɪð mi ən sɛn skaʊts θɹu ðoʊz ɡeɪtweɪz ə jʊɹz tə si ɪf ə fɔɹs ɹɪli ɪz kʌmɪŋ."

"Give us a few hours," Yoeli said. "Hold the city with me and send scouts through those gateways of yours to see if a force really is coming."

"ə fju aʊɝz?" ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "wɪð ə hoʊl ɪn jəɹ wɔl? wɝ oʊvɝwɛlmd, joʊli."

"A few hours?" Ituralde said. "With a hole in your wall? We're overwhelmed, Yoeli."

"pliz," joʊli plɛd. "ɑɹ jə nɑt wʌn ə ðoʊz ðeɪ neɪm ɡɹeɪt kæptən? ʃoʊ mi wʌt ðət taɪɾəl minz, lɔɹd ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi."

"Please," Yoeli pled. "Are you not one of those they name Great Captain? Show me what that title means, Lord Rodel Ituralde."

ɪɾɝɑldi tɝnd, bæk ət ðə bɹoʊkən wɔl. bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɪn ðə pæləsəz tɑp ɹum, hi kəd hɪɹ ɪz ɔfəsɝz ɡæðɝɪŋ. ðə laɪn ət ðə wɔl wɑz fɹæɡməntɪŋ. ɪt wʊdn bi lɔŋ naʊ.

Ituralde turned, back at the broken wall. Behind him, in the palace's top room, he could hear his officers gathering. The line at the wall was fragmenting. It wouldn't be long now.

ʃoʊ mi wʌt ðət minz.

Show me what that means.

pɝhæps . . .

Perhaps . . .

"taɪməθ, ɑɹ jə hɪɹ?" ɪɾɝɑldi bɛloʊd.

"Tymoth, are you here?" Ituralde bellowed.

ə ɹɛd-hɛɹd mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt stɛpt ɑntu ðə bælkəni. hid bi ɪn kəmæn ə ði æʃəmən naʊ ðət dip hæd fɔlən. "hɪɹ, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi."

A red-haired man in a black coat stepped onto the balcony. He'd be in command of the Asha'man now that Deepe had fallen. "Here, Lord Ituralde."

"ɡæðɝ jəɹ mɛn," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛɾ ɝdʒənli. "teɪk kəmæn ə ðət ɡæp ən əv ðə soʊlʒɝz ðəɹ ɹitʃɹit. aɪ wɑn ði æʃəmən tə hoʊl ðə bɹitʃ. aɪ niɾ ə hæf-aʊɝ. aɪ wɑn ɔl ə jəɹ ɛnɝdʒi -  ɛvɹiθɪŋ juv ɡɑt - tə hɪt ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks. jə hɪɹ mi? ɛvɹiθɪŋ juv ɡɑt. ɪf jə kən tʃænəl ɪnʌf tə laɪɾ ə kændəl wən ðɪs ɪz dʌn, əl əv jəɹ haɪdz."

"Gather your men," Ituralde said urgently. "Take command of that gap and have the soldiers there retreat. I want the Asha'man to hold the breach. I need a half-hour. I want all of your energy -  everything you've got - to hit those Trollocs. You hear me? Everything you've got. If you can channel enough to light a candle when this is done, I'll have your hides."

"sɝ," ði æʃəmən sɛd. "aʊɝ ɹitʃɹit?"

"Sir," the Asha'man said. "Our retreat?"

"liv ænteɪl ɪn ðə hilɪŋ tɛnt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "hi kən meɪk ə lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ ði æʃəmən tə ɹʌn. bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, hoʊl ðət bɹitʃ!"

"Leave Antail in the Healing tent," Ituralde said. "He can make a large enough gateway for the Asha'man to run. But everyone else, hold that breach!"

taɪməθ dæʃt əweɪ. "joʊli," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "jɔɹ dʒɑb ɪz tə ɡæðɝ jəɹ fɔɹsɪz ən stɑp əm fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪɾi laɪk . . ." hi pɔzd. hid bɪn əbaʊt tə seɪ, "laɪk ɪts tɑɹmən blʌɾi ɡdən." bɝn mi. ". . . laɪk ðəɹ ɪz noʊbɑdi ɪn kəmænd. ɪf wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə hoʊld, wɪl nid tə bi ɔɹɡənaɪzd ən dɪsəplənd. aɪ nid fɔɹ kævəlɹi kʌmpəniz fɔɹmd ʌp ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ɪn tɛn mɪnəts.

Tymoth dashed away. "Yoeli," Ituralde said, "your job is to gather your forces and stop them from running through the city like . . ." He paused. He'd been about to say, "like it's Tarmon bloody Gai'don." Burn me. ". . . like there is nobody in command. If we are going to hold, we will need to be organized and disciplined. I need four cavalry companies formed up in the courtyard in ten minutes.

ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝz."

Give the orders."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," joʊli sɛd, snæpɪŋ tə ɪt.

"Yes, my Lord," Yoeli said, snapping to it.

"oʊ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ. "aɪm gɑnə niɾ ə kʌpəl ə kɑɹtloʊdz əɹ faɪɝwʊd, əz mɛni bæɹəlz ʌv ɔɪl əz jə kən kʌm ʌp wɪð, ən ɔl ə ðə wundəɾ ɪn iðɝ ɑɹmi hu kən stɪl ɹʌn bʌɾ u hæv feɪs əɹ ɑɹm wunz. ɔlsoʊ, ɡɛt mi ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə sɪɾi huz ɛvɝ hɛld ə baʊ. ɡoʊ!"

"Oh," Ituralde said, turning. "I'm going to need a couple of cartloads or firewood, as many barrels of oil as you can come up with, and all of the wounded in either army who can still run but who have face or arm wounds. Also, get me anyone in the city who's ever held a bow. Go!"

nɪɹli ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, ɪɾɝɑldi stʊd, hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, weɪt-ɪŋ. hid muvd ɪn fɹəm ðə bælkəni tə lʊk aʊɾ ə wɪndoʊ, əz tə nɑɾ ɛks-poʊz hɪmsɛlf. bʌɾ i stɪl hæɾ ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ðə faɪɾɪŋ.

Nearly an hour later, Ituralde stood, hands clasped behind his back, wait-ing. He'd moved in from the balcony to look out a window, as to not ex-pose himself. But he still had a good view of the fighting.

aʊtsaɪd ðə pæləs, ði æʃəmən laɪn wɑz faɪnəli wikənɪŋ. ðeɪd ɡɪvən ɪm ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ, blæstɪŋ bæk weɪv æftɝ weɪv ə tʃɹɑləks ɪn ən ɑsəm dɪspleɪ ʌv paʊɝ. blɛsədli, ði ɛnəmi tʃænlɝz hæd nɑɾ əpɪɹd. æftɝ ðət ʃoʊ ʌv paʊɝ, hoʊpfəli ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹeɪn ən ɪɡzɔstəd.

Outside the palace, the Asha'man line was finally weakening. They'd given him the better part of an hour, blasting back wave after wave of Trollocs in an awesome display of Power. Blessedly, the enemy channelers had not appeared. After that show of power, hopefully they were drained and exhausted.

ɪt fɛlt laɪk dʌsk, wɪð ðoʊz əpɹɛsɪv klaʊdz oʊvɝhɛɾ ən ðə mæsəz ə fɪɡjɝz dɑɹkənɪŋ ðə hɪlsaɪdz bɪɑn ðə sɪɾi. ðə tʃɹɑləks, fɔɹtʃənətli, dɪdn bɹɪŋ læɾɝz əɹ sidʒ taʊɝz. oʊnli weɪv æftɝ weɪv ət ðət bɹitʃ, wɪpt ɪndə ətæk baɪ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl.

It felt like dusk, with those oppressive clouds overhead and the masses of figures darkening the hillsides beyond the city. The Trollocs, fortunately, didn't bring ladders or siege towers. Only wave after wave at that breach, whipped into attack by the Myrddraal.

ɔlɹɛɾi, səm ə ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn wɝ lɪmpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɹitʃ, lʊkɪŋ ɪɡzɔstəd.

Already, some of the black-coated men were limping away from the breach, looking exhausted.

ðə læs fju θɹu ə faɪnəl blæst ə faɪɝ ən ɪɹʌptɪŋ ɝθ, ðən fɑloʊd ðɛɹ kəmpænjənz. ðeɪ lɛf ðə ɡæp kəmplitli oʊpən ən ʌndɪfɛndəd, əz ɔɹɾɝd.

The last few threw a final blast of Fire and erupting Earth, then followed their companions. They left the gap completely open and undefended, as ordered.

kʌm ɑn, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔɾ əz ðə smoʊk klɪɹd.

Come on, Ituralde thought as the smoke cleared.

ðə tʃɹɑləks pɪɹd θɹu ðə smoʊk, klaɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kɑɹkəsɪz ə ðoʊz ði æʃəmən hæd kɪld. ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn loʊpt ɑn hʊvz əɹ θɪk pɔz. səm snɪf ði ɛɹ.

The Trollocs peered through the smoke, climbing over the carcasses of those the Asha'man had killed. The Shadowspawn loped on hooves or thick paws. Some sniffed the air.

ðə stʃɹits ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡæp wɝ fɪld wɪð kɛɹfəli pleɪs mɛn u wɝ blʌɾid ən wundəd. ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə skɹim əz ðə tʃɹɑləks ɛntɝd, ɹʌnɪŋ əz kəmændəd. laɪkli nʌn ə ðɛɹ fɪɹ wɑz feɪnd. ðə sin lʊk mɔɹ tɛɹəbəl naʊ ðət mɛni ʌv ðə nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋz wɝ smoʊldɝɪŋ, əz ɪf fɹəm ðə blæst, ɹufs ɑn faɪɝ, smoʊk pɔɹɪŋ fɹəm wɪndoʊz. ðə tʃɹɑləks wʊdnt noʊ ðət ðə sleɪt ɹufs hæd bɪn dɪzaɪnd nɑt tə bɝn, ən lɔz kɛp bɪldɪŋz fɹəm kənteɪnɪŋ tu mʌtʃ wʊd.

The streets inside the gap were filled with carefully placed men who were bloodied and wounded. They began to scream as the Trollocs entered, running as commanded. Likely none of their fear was feigned. The scene looked more terrible now that many of the nearby buildings were smoldering, as if from the blast, roofs on fire, smoke pouring from windows. The Trollocs wouldn't know that the slate roofs had been designed not to burn, and laws kept buildings from containing too much wood.

ɪɾɝɑldi hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ. ðə tʃɹɑləks bɹoʊk, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, haʊlɪŋ ən ɹɔɹɪŋ, ɡɹups bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ sɔ ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə pɪlɪdʒ ən slɔɾɝ.

Ituralde held his breath. The Trollocs broke, running into the city, howling and roaring, groups breaking apart as they saw the opportunity to pillage and slaughter.

ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪɾɝɑldi slæmd oʊpən, ən joʊli heɪsən ɪn. "ðə læst ɹæŋks ɑɹ pleɪst. ɪz ɪt wɝkɪŋ?"

The door behind Ituralde slammed open, and Yoeli hastened in. "The last ranks are placed. Is it working?"

ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdn ænsɝ; ðə pɹuf wɑz bɪloʊ. ðə tʃɹɑləks əsum ðɛɹ bæɾəl wʌn - ðə blæstɪŋ paʊɝ ə ði æʃəmən hæd ði ɛɹ ʌv wʌn faɪnəl stænd, ən ðə sɪɾi əpɪɹd tə bi ɪn keɪɑs. ðə tʃɹɑləks ɔl ɹæn daʊn ðə stʃɹits wɪð ɑbviəs ɡli. ivən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl u ɛntɝɾ əpɪɹɾ əɾ iz.

Ituralde didn't answer; the proof was below. The Trollocs assumed their battle won - the blasting Power of the Asha'man had the air of one final stand, and the city appeared to be in chaos. The Trollocs all ran down the streets with obvious glee. Even the Myrddraal who entered appeared at ease.

ðə tʃɹɑləks əvɔɪɾəd ðə bɝnɪŋ bɪldɪŋz ən ðə pæləs, wɪtʃ wɑz wɔld. ðeɪ muv dipɝ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, pɝsuɪŋ ðə fliɪŋ soʊlʒɝz daʊn ə waɪɾ ævənu ɑn ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi.

The Trollocs avoided the burning buildings and the palace, which was walled. They moved deeper into the city, pursuing the fleeing soldiers down a wide avenue on the eastern side of the city.

kɛɹfəli paɪld ɹʌbəl ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə bʌlk ə ðɛm daʊn ðɪs ævənu.

Carefully piled rubble encouraged the bulk of them down this avenue.

"du juv æspɝeɪʃənz ə biɪŋ ə dʒɛnɝəl, kæptən joʊli?" ɪɾɝɑldi æsk sɔfli.

"Do you have aspirations of being a general, Captain Yoeli?" Ituralde asked softly.

"maɪ æspɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt," joʊli sɛd. "bʌɾ ə mæn wəd bi ə ful nɑt tə hoʊp tə lɝn."

"My aspirations are not important," Yoeli said. "But a man would be a fool not to hope to learn."

"ðɛn peɪ ətɛnʃən tə ðɪs lɛsən, sʌn." bɪloʊ, ʃʌɾɝz ɑn wɪndoʊz wɝ flʌŋ oʊpən ɑn bɪldɪŋz əlɔŋ ði ævənu ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd teɪkən boʊmən sɝdʒd aʊɾ ɑntu bælkəniz. "ɪf jə ɛvɝ əv soʊ mʌtʃ əz ən ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət jəɹ duɪŋ wʌt jəɹ ɛnəmi ɪkspɛks jə tə du, ðən də sʌmθɪŋ ɛls."

"Then pay attention to this lesson, son." Below, shutters on windows were flung open on buildings along the avenue the Trollocs had taken Bowmen surged out onto balconies. "If you ever have so much as an impression that you're doing what your enemy expects you to do, then do something else."

ði æɹoʊz fɛl, ən tʃɹɑləks daɪd. lɑɹdʒ kɹɔsboʊz ðət ʃɑt kwɔɹəlz ɔlmoʊs ðə saɪz ə spɪɹz tɑɹɡəɾɪd ðə feɪdz, ən mɛni kəd bi sin lɝtʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə peɪvmənt, nɑt noʊɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd, əz skɔɹz ə tʃɹɑləks lɪŋk tə ðɛm fɛl. kənfjuzd, ɛnɹeɪdʒd, ðə stɪl-lɪvɪŋ kɹitʃɝz bɪɡæn tə bɛloʊ ən paʊn ɪn ðə dɔɹz ə ðə bɪldɪŋz fɪld wɪð ɑɹtʃɝz. bʌɾ əz ðeɪ dɪd soʊ, ðə θʌndɝ bɪɡæn. hʊfbits. joʊli ɛs bɛs kævəlɹi tʃɑɹdʒ daʊn ðə stʃɹits, lænsɪz fɔɹwɝd. ðeɪ tʃɹæmpəl ðə tʃɹɑləks, slɔɾɝɪŋ ðɛm.

The arrows fell, and Trollocs died. Large crossbows that shot quarrels almost the size of spears targeted the Fades, and many could be seen lurching across the pavement, not knowing that they were already dead, as scores of Trollocs linked to them fell. Confused, enraged, the still-living creatures began to bellow and pound in the doors of the buildings filled with archers. But as they did so, the thunder began. Hoofbeats. Yoeli s best cavalry charged down the streets, lances forward. They trampled the Trollocs, slaughtering them.

ðə sɪɾi bɪkeɪm ən ɪnɔɹməs æmbʊʃ. ə mæn kʊdn æsk fəɹ bɛɾɝ væntɪdʒɪz ðən ðoʊz bɪldɪŋz, ən ðə stʃɹits wɝ waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə əlaʊ ə tʃɑɹdʒ baɪ ðoʊz u nu ðə leɪaʊt. ðə tʃɹɑləks wɛn fɹəm bɛloʊɪŋ ɪn dʒɔɪ tə skɹimɪŋ ɪn peɪn, ən skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðɛɹ heɪs tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd baɪ ðə bɹoʊkən wɔl.

The city became an enormous ambush. A man couldn't ask for better vantages than those buildings, and the streets were wide enough to allow a charge by those who knew the layout. The Trollocs went from bellowing in joy to screaming in pain, and scrambled over one another in their haste to get away. They entered the courtyard by the broken wall.

ðə sɑldəiən hɔɹsmən fɑloʊd, ðɛɹ hʊvz ən flæŋks wɛt wɪð ðə nɑkʃəs blʌɾ ə ðə fɔlən. mɛn əpɪɹɾ ət wɪndoʊz ʌv "bɝnɪŋ" bɪldɪŋz - ðə faɪɝz kɛɹfəli kɹieɪɾəd ɪn sɛkʃənd-ɔf ɹumz - ən bɪɡæn lusɪŋ æɹoʊz daʊn ɪndə ðə lɑɹdʒ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ʌðɝz tɔs nu lænsɪz tə ðə hɔɹsmən, hu, ɹikwɪpt, laɪn ʌp ən ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks. ði æɹoʊz stɑp fɔlɪŋ, ən ðə kævəlɹi meɪɾ ə swipɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ kɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd.

The Saldaean horsemen followed, their hooves and flanks wet with the noxious blood of the fallen. Men appeared at windows of "burning" buildings - the fires carefully created in sectioned-off rooms - and began loosing arrows down into the large courtyard. Others tossed new lances to the horsemen, who, reequipped, lined up and rode into the Trollocs. The arrows stopped falling, and the cavalry made a sweeping charge crossed the courtyard.

hʌnʒɹədz ə tʃɹɑləks daɪd. pɝhæps θaʊzənz. ðoʊz ðət dɪdn daɪ skɹæmbəld aʊɾ ə ðə ɡæp.

Hundreds of Trollocs died. Perhaps thousands. Those that didn't die scrambled out of the gap.

moʊst ə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl flɛd. ðoʊz ðət dɪd nɑt wɝ tɑɹɡəts fəɹ ði ɑɹtʃɝz. kɪlɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm kəd kɪl dʌzənz ə tʃɹɑləks lɪŋk tə ðɛm. ðə feɪdz wɛn daʊn - mɛni spɹaʊɾɪŋ dʌzənz ʌv æɹoʊz.

Most of the Myrddraal fled. Those that did not were targets for the archers. Killing one of them could kill dozens of Trollocs linked to them. The Fades went down - many sprouting dozens of arrows.

"aɪl ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ tə junaɪɾ ən hoʊl ðə bɹitʃ əɡɛn," joʊli sɛɾ iɡɝli.

"I'll give the order to unite and hold the breach again," Yoeli said eagerly.

"noʊ.." ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

"No.." Ituralde said.

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"faɪɾɪŋ ət ðə bɹitʃ wɪl ɡeɪn əs nʌθɪŋ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝz fəɹ ðə mɛn tə muv tə dɪfɹən bɪldɪŋz, ən əv ði ɑɹtʃɝz teɪk dɪfɹən pəzɪʃənz. ɑɹ ðəɹ wɛɹhaʊzɪz əɹ ʌðɝ lɑɹdʒ bɪldɪŋz ðət kən haɪd ðə hɔɹsmən? muv əm ðɛɹ, kwɪkli. ən ðən wi weɪt."

"Fighting at the breach will gain us nothing," Ituralde said. "Give the orders for the men to move to different buildings, and have the archers take different positions. Are there warehouses or other large buildings that can hide the horsemen? Move them there, quickly. And then we wait."

"ðeɪ woʊn bi kɑɾ əɡɛn."

"They won't be caught again."

"noʊ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "bʌt ðəl bi sloʊ ən kɔʃəs. ɪf wi faɪɾ əm hɛɾ ɑn, wi luz. ɪf wi hoʊld, baɪ taɪm, wi wɪn. ðæts ði oʊnli weɪ aʊɾ ə ðɪs joʊli. tə sɝvaɪv əntɪl hɛlp kʌmz. ɪf ɪts kʌmɪŋ."

"No," Ituralde said. "But they'll be slow and cautious. If we fight them head on, we lose. If we hold, buy time, we win. That's the only way out of this Yoeli. To survive until help comes. If it's coming."

joʊli nɑɾəd.

Yoeli nodded.

"aʊɝ nɛks tʃɹæp woʊn kɪl əz mɛni," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "bʌt tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ kaʊɝdz ət hɑɹt. ðə nɑlədʒ ðəɾ ɛni ɹoʊdweɪ kəd sʌɾənli tɝn ɪndə ə dɛθ tʃɹæp wɪl meɪk əm hɛzəteɪt, ən wɪl ɝn əs mɔɹ taɪm ðən wəd luzɪŋ hæf ʌv əɹ mɛn hoʊldɪŋ ðət wɔl."

"Our next trap won't kill as many," Ituralde said, "but Trollocs are cowards at heart. The knowledge that any roadway could suddenly turn into a death trap will make them hesitate, and will earn us more time than would losing half of our men holding that wall."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," joʊli sɛd. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "bʌt . . . dʌzn ðɪs min ðət ðəɹ æntɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ ʌs? ðɪs feɪz ə ðə plæn wɪl wɝk oʊnli kəz ðeɪ ɪkspɛkt əɹ æmbʊʃɪz."

"All right," Yoeli said. He hesitated. "But . . . doesn't this mean that they're anticipating us? This phase of the plan will work only because they expect our ambushes."

"aɪ səpoʊz ðæts tʃɹu."

"I suppose that's true."

"soʊ ʃʊdnt wi də sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɹənt? jə sɛd ðəɾ ɪf wiv ɡɑɾ ə hɪn ðət ði ɛnəmi noʊz wʌt wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, wi ʃəd tʃeɪnʒ plænz."

"So shouldn't we do something different? You said that if we've got a hint that the enemy knows what we're going to do, we should change plans."

"jɔɹ θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt tu mʌtʃ, sʌn. ɡoʊ də əz aɪ kəmændəd."

"You're thinking about it too much, son. Go do as I commanded."

"ɝ, jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd." hi hɝiɾ əweɪ.

"Er, yes, my Lord." He hurried away.

ðɪs, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt, ɪz waɪ aɪ ʃəd nɛvɝ titʃ tæktɪks. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə ɪkspleɪn tə stuɾənts ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹul ðət tʃɹʌmpt ɔl ə ði ʌðɝz: ɔlweɪz tʃɹʌs jəɹ ɪnstɪŋks. ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd bi əfɹeɪd. hi kəd juz ðæt. hid juz ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ ɡeɪv hɪm.

This, Ituralde thought, is why I should never teach tactics. It was hard to explain to students that there was a rule that trumped all of the others: Always trust your instincts. The Trollocs would be afraid. He could use that. He'd use anything they gave him.

hi dɪdn laɪk tə θɪŋk tu lɔŋ əbaʊt ðət ɹul, lɛst i dwɛl ɑn ðə fæk ðət hid vaɪəleɪɾɪd ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. kəz ɪz ɛvɹi ɪnstɪŋk skɹim ðəɾ i ʃʊɾə əbændən ðɪs sɪɾi aʊɝz əɡoʊ.

He didn't like to think too long about that rule, lest he dwell on the fact that he'd violated it already. Because his every instinct screamed that he should have abandoned this city hours ago.


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

eɪ tɛɹəbəl filɪŋ


A Terrible Feeling

wʌɾ ɪz pɛɹɪn plɑɾɪŋ, dʒju θɪŋk?" bɹəleɪn æskt əz ʃi stʃɹoʊl bɪsaɪd feɪl ən æliændɝ.

What is Perrin plotting, do you think?" Berelain asked as she strolled beside Faile and Alliandre.

feɪl dɪdn ænsɝ. ðə leɪɾ æftɝnun wɑz sɔfli lɪt baɪ ə dɪstən sʌn ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn klaʊdz. sun ɪt wəd meɪk ðə hɝaɪzən bɝn əz ɪt sæŋk daʊn fəɹ ðə naɪt. ɪn tu deɪz, pɛɹɪn wəd ɡoʊ ɑn tʃɹaɪəl. hid dɪleɪd spəsɪfɪkli, ʃi nu, tə ɡeɪn mɔɹ taɪm fəɹ ði æʃəmən tə wɝk aʊt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ pɹɑbləm wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz.

Faile didn't answer. The late afternoon was softly lit by a distant sun shrouded in clouds. Soon it would make the horizon burn as it sank down for the night. In two days, Perrin would go on trial. He'd delayed specifically, she knew, to gain more time for the Ashaman to work out the strange problem with gateways.

ðɛɹ ɑɹmi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ, stɪl mɔɹ pipəl flʌɾɪŋ tə ðɛm. skaʊt ɹɪpɔɹts ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət ðə waɪtkloʊk fɔɹs wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ əz wɛl. mɔɹ sloʊli, bʌt stɪl ɡɹoʊɪŋ. ɪn deɪz laɪk ðiz, ən ɑɹmi wɑz ə sɪmbəl ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ən - ət ðə vɛɹi list - fud.

Their army was growing, still more people flooding to them. Scout reports indicated that the Whitecloak force was growing as well. More slowly, but still growing. In days like these, an army was a symbol of strength and - at the very least - food.

ə stæn ə fɪŋɡɹut tʃɹiz ɡlʌɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ ə ðə stʃɹim nɪɹ pɛɹɪnz wɔɹ kæmp.

A stand of fingeroot trees glutted themselves on the water of the stream near Perrin's war camp.

sətʃ stʃɹeɪnʒ plæns ðeɪ wɝ, wɪð ðoʊz ɹuts ðət dɪpt ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ. tʃɹʌŋks laɪk floʊɪŋ ɡlæs ðət hæd puld waɪl hɑɹɾənɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ laɪk əm ʌp ɪn sɑldɑiə. ɪt sim ðət tu ɹɔŋ stɛps hɪɹ kəd lid jə ɪndə ə swɑmp.

Such strange plants they were, with those roots that dipped into the water. Trunks like flowing glass that had pooled while hardening. There was nothing like them up in Saldaea. It seemed that two wrong steps here could lead you into a swamp.

"noʊ ænsɝ fəɹ mi?" bɹəleɪn æskt. ʃi sim dɪstʃɹæktəd ðiz deɪz. "aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ.

"No answer for me?" Berelain asked. She seemed distracted these days. "I've been thinking.

pɝhæps ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə sɛn ən ɛnvɔɪ tə ðə waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi. dʒju θɪŋk pɛɹɪn wəɾ əlaʊ mi tə ɡoʊ ən spik wɪð ðɛm? pɝhæps aɪ kəd meɪk ə pɝsənəl əpil ɑn ɪz bɪhæf."

Perhaps it would be good to send an envoy to the Whitecloak army. Do you think Perrin would allow me to go and speak with them? Perhaps I could make a personal appeal on his behalf."

ʃi kɛp bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðət tɑpɪk. "noʊ," feɪl sɛd. "ju noʊ hɪz maɪn ɪz meɪɾ ʌp ɑn ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl, bɹəleɪn."

She kept bringing up that topic. "No," Faile said. "You know his mind is made up on this trial, Berelain."

ðə fɝs pɝst əɹ lɪps, bʌt dɪd nɑt pɹɛs fɝðɝ. ðə θɹi kəntɪnjuɾ ɛɹ wɔk, əkʌmpənid baɪ tɛn meɪɾənz. wʌns, feɪl maɪɾ əv kəmbaɪn əbaʊt ði ətɛnʃən. ðət wɑz bɪfɔɹ ʃid bɪn teɪkən soʊ ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli, ən soʊ izəli.

The First pursed her lips, but did not press further. The three continued heir walk, accompanied by ten Maidens. Once, Faile might have combined about the attention. That was before she'd been taken so unexpectedly, and so easily.

ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ʃi sɔ ə smɔl ɡɹup ə ɹɛfjudʒiz livɪŋ ðə kæmp, wɔkɪŋ əweɪ tə ðə saʊθist, kɹɔs-kʌntʃɹi. bɪfɔɹ θɪŋz hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ wɪð ðə ɡeɪtweɪz, əbaʊt tɛn θaʊzən hæd bɪn sɛn tə ɹʊɹəl ɛɹiəz ɪn kɛɹhin. ɔl hæɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə ɹɪmeɪn kwaɪət. pɛɹɪn dɪdnt wɑn ɪz loʊkeɪʃən noʊn jɛt. wɪmən wəd bi stɪl, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs ðə mɛn wəd ɡɑsəp; ðeɪ ɔlweɪz dɪd.

In the distance, she saw a small group of refugees leaving the camp, walking away to the southeast, cross-country. Before things had gone wrong with the gateways, about ten thousand had been sent to rural areas in Cairhien. All had instructions to remain quiet. Perrin didn't want his location known yet. Women would be still, but of course the men would gossip; they always did.

fju nu ðət ɡeɪtweɪz feɪld; pɛɹɪn hæd toʊl ðə pipəl ðəɾ i niɾəd ði æʃəmən stʃɹɔŋ, ɪn keɪs ðəɹ wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə waɪt-kloʊks. ɪt wɑz tʃɹu ɪnʌf. stɪl, səm ɹɛfjudʒiz hæɾ æsk tə liv, ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn fʊt. tə ðiz, feɪl ɡeɪv bɪts ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ ə dʒuəl fɹəm sɪvænəz stɔɹ ən wɪʃt əm ðə bɛst. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ mɛni wɑntəd tə ɹɪtɝn tə hoʊmz ðət wɝ ɪn sintʃæn- kəntʃɹoʊld lænz.

Few knew that gateways failed; Perrin had told the people that he needed the Asha'man strong, in case there was righting with the White-cloaks. It was true enough. Still, some refugees had asked to leave, going on foot. To these, Faile gave bits of gold or a jewel from Sevanna's store and wished them the best. She was surprised at how many wanted to return to homes that were in Seanchan- controlled lands.

dɪspaɪt ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝz, ðə saɪz ə pɛɹɪnz fɔɹs wɑz swɛlɪŋ deɪ baɪ deɪ. feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz pæst ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup pɹæktəsɪŋ wɪð sɔɹdz. ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz u hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹeɪn wɝ naʊ səm twɛnti-faɪv θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ. ðeɪ pɹæktəs leɪɾ ɪndə ðə deɪ, ən feɪl kəd stɪl hɪɹ bɑɹkt ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm tɑɹn.

Despite the departures, the size of Perrin's force was swelling day by day. Faile and the others passed a large group practicing with swords. The refugees who had decided to train were now some twenty-five thousand strong. They practiced late into the day, and Faile could still hear barked orders from Tarn.

"wɛl." bɹəleɪn kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ mjuzɪŋz. "wʌt wɪl pɛɹɪn du? waɪ sɛɾ ʌp ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl? hi wɑns sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks." ʃi stɛpt ɝaʊn ə nɑɹl fɪŋɡɹut. ðə fɝst, laɪk soʊ mɛni ʌðɝz, ɹɛd mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪndə pɛɹɪnz ækʃənz ðən ðəɹ wɑz tə faɪnd. hid bi əmjuzd ɪf i nu ðə plɑts ðeɪ əskɹaɪb tə hɪm.

"Well." Berelain continued her musings. "What will Perrin do? Why set up this trial? He wants something from those Whitecloaks." She stepped around a gnarled fingeroot. The First, like so many others, read much more into Perrin's actions than there was to find. He'd be amused if he knew the plots they ascribed to him.

ən ʃi kleɪmz tə ʌndɝstæn mɛn, feɪl θɔt. pɛɹɪn wɑz baɪ noʊ minz stupəd, nɔɹ wɑz i ðə sɪmpəl mæn i səmtaɪmz kleɪm tə bi. hi plænd, hi θɔt, ən i wɑz kɛɹfəl. bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlsoʊ dɝɛkt. dɪlɪbɝɪt. wən i sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, hi mɛn ɪt.

And she claims to understand men, Faile thought. Perrin was by no means stupid, nor was he the simple man he sometimes claimed to be. He planned, he thought, and he was careful. But he was also direct. Deliberate. When he said something, he meant it.

"aɪ əɡɹi wɪð bɹəleɪn," æliændɝ sɛd. "wi ʃəd dʒʌs liv, mɑɹtʃ əweɪ. əɹ ətæk ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks."

"I agree with Berelain," Alliandre said. "We should just leave, march away. Or attack those Whitecloaks."

feɪl ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪt bɑðɝz pɛɹɪn wən pipəl θɪŋk i dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. əz lɔŋ əz ðə waɪtkloʊks kəntɪnju tə ɪnsɪs hiz ə mɝɾɝɝ, hɪz neɪm wɪl nɑt bi klɪɹ." hi wɑz biɪŋ bʊlhɛɾɪd ən ful-ɪʃ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə noʊbɪləɾi əbaʊɾ ɪt.

Faile shook her head. "It bothers Perrin when people think he did something wrong. As long as the Whitecloaks continue to insist he is a murderer, his name will not be clear." He was being bullheaded and fool-ish, but there was a nobility about it.

soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt dɪdnt ɡɛɾ ɪm kɪld. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi lʌvd ɪm fəɹ ðət vɛɹi sɛns ʌv ɑnɝ. tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪm wəd bi ɪl ædvaɪzd, soʊ ʃi hæd tə meɪk sɝɾən ʌðɝz dɪdn teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ə hɪm.

So long as it didn't get him killed. However, she loved him for that very sense of honor. Changing him would be ill advised, so she had to make certain others didn't take advantage of him.

əz ʃi ɔlweɪz dɪd wən ðeɪ dɪskʌs ðə waɪtkloʊks, bɹəleɪn ɡɑɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ lʊk ɪn əɹ aɪz, ən ʃi ɡlænst - pɝhæps ʌnkɑnʃəsli - ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ðɛɹ ɑɹmi kæmpt. laɪt. ʃi wɑzn gɑnə æsk əɡɛn ɪf ʃi kəd ɡoʊ spik tə ðɛm? ʃi hæd kʌm ʌp wɪð ə dʌzən dɪfɹən ɹizənz waɪ ʃi wɑntəd tə.

As she always did when they discussed the Whitecloaks, Berelain got a strange look in her eyes, and she glanced - perhaps unconsciously - in the direction their army camped. Light. She wasn't going to ask again if she could go speak to them? She had come up with a dozen different reasons why she wanted to.

feɪl noʊɾəst ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɪŋkɑnspɪkwəs əz ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə kæmp, kipɪŋ peɪs wɪð feɪl ən ðɛɹ ɡɑɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ pɹɑməneɪd. pɛɹɪn wɑntəɾ əɹ wɛl pɹətɛktəd.

Faile noticed a large group of soldiers trying to look inconspicuous as they rounded the inside of the camp, keeping pace with Faile and their guards on their promenade. Perrin wanted her well protected.

"ðɪs jʌŋ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," æliændɝ sɛɾ aɪdli. "hi lʊks kwaɪt stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ɪn ðət waɪt junəfɔɹm, wʊdn jə seɪ? ɪf jə kən ɡɛt pæs ðət sʌnbɝst ɑn ɪz kloʊk. sətʃ ə bjuɾəfəl mæn."

"This young Lord Captain Commander," Alliandre said idly. "He looks quite striking in that white uniform, wouldn't you say? If you can get past that sunburst on his cloak. Such a beautiful man."

"oʊ?" bɹieɪn sɛd. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, wɔɹm kʌlɝ ɹoʊz ɪn əɹ tʃiks.

"Oh?" Bereiain said. Surprisingly, warm color rose in her cheeks.

"aɪɾ ɔlweɪz hɝd ðət mɔɹɡeɪsəz stɛpsʌn wɑz ə hænsəm mæn," æliændɝ kəntɪnjud. "bʌɾ aɪ hædn æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ɪm biɪŋ soʊ . . . pɹɪstin."

"I'd always heard that Morgase's stepson was a handsome man," Alliandre continued. "But I hadn't anticipated him being so . . . pristine."

"laɪk ə stætʃu kɑɹv fɹəm mɑɹbəl," bɹieɪn wɪspɝd, "ə ɹɛlɪk fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ə pɝfək θɪŋ lɛf bɪhaɪnd. fəɹ əs tə wɝʃəp."

"Like a statue carved from marble," Bereiain whispered, "a relic from the Age of Legends. A perfect thing left behind. For us to worship."

"hiz pæsəbəl," feɪl sɛd wɪð ə snɪf. "aɪ pɹəfɝ ə bɪɹɾəd feɪs, maɪsɛlf."

"He's passable," Faile said with a sniff. "I prefer a bearded face, myself."

ɪt wɑzn ə laɪ - ʃi lʌvd ə bɪɹɾəd feɪs, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz hænsəm. hi hæɾ ə bɝli paʊɝ tə hɪm ðət wɑz kwaɪɾ əpilɪŋ. bʌt ðɪs ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd wɑz . . . wɛl, ɪt wɑzn fɛɹ tə kəmpɛɹ ɪm tə pɛɹɪn. ðət wəd bi laɪk kəmpɛɹɪŋ ə steɪnd ɡlæs wɪndoʊ tə ə kæbənət meɪd baɪ ə mæstɝ kɑɹpəntɝ. boʊθ wɝ ɛksələn ɪɡzæmpəlz ə ðɛɹ kɹæft, ən ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə weɪ ðɛm əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. bʌt ðə wɪndoʊ sɝɾənli dɪd ʃaɪn.

It wasn't a lie - she loved a bearded face, and Perrin was handsome. He had a burly power to him that was quite appealing. But this Galad Damodred was . . . well, it wasn't fair to compare him to Perrin. That would be like comparing a stained glass window to a cabinet made by a master carpenter. Both were excellent examples of their craft, and it was hard to weigh them against one another. But the window certainly did shine.

bɹəleɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən sim dɪstənt. ʃi wɑz dɛfənətli teɪkən wɪð dəmədʒɹd. sətʃ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm fəɹ ɪt tə hæv hæpənd. feɪl toʊl bɹieɪn ðət faɪndɪŋ ənʌðɝ mæn fəɹ əɹ ətɛnʃənz wəd hɛlp wɪð ðə ɹumɝz, bʌt ðə waɪtkloʊk kəmændɝ? hæd ðə wʊmən lɔst ɔl sɛns?

Berelain's expression seemed distant. She was definitely taken with Damodred. Such a short time for it to have happened. Faile told Bereiain that finding another man for her attentions would help with the rumors, but the Whitecloak commander? Had the woman lost all sense?

"soʊ wʌt də wi du?" æliændɝ æskt əz ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ðə saʊθ saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp, hæfweɪ tə ðə pɔɪn fɹəm wɪtʃ ðeɪd stɑɹɾəd.

"So what do we do?" Alliandre asked as they rounded the south side of the camp, halfway to the point from which they'd started.

"əbaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks?" feɪl æskt.

"About the Whitecloaks?" Faile asked.

"əbaʊt meɪaɪɡdɪn," æliændɝ sɛd. "mɔɹɡeɪs."

"About Maighdin," Alliandre said. "Morgase."

"aɪ kæn hɛlp filɪŋ ðət ʃi tʊk ædvæntɪdʒ ə maɪ kaɪndnəs," feɪl sɛd. "æftɝ ɔl wi wɛn θɹu təɡɛðɝ, ʃi dɪdn tɛl mi hu ʃi wɑz?

"I can't help feeling that she took advantage of my kindness," Faile said. "After all we went through together, she didn't tell me who she was?

"ju sim tə bi dɪtɝmən tə ɡɪv əɹ vɛɹi lɪɾəl kɹɛɾət," bɹieɪn sɛd.

"You seem to be determined to give her very little credit," Bereiain said.

feɪl dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ. ʃid bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌt pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən i wɑz pɹɑbli ɹaɪt. feɪl ʃəd nɑt bi soʊ æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝ. ɪf mɔɹɡeɪs ɹɪli hæd bɪn fliɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ɪt wɑz ə mɪɹəkəl ðət ʃi wɑz stɪl əlaɪv. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd laɪɾ əbaʊɾ u ʃi wɑz, wən fɝs miɾɪŋ pɛɹɪn.

Faile didn't reply. She'd been thinking about what Perrin said, and he was probably right. Faile should not be so angry with her. If Morgase really had been fleeing one of the Forsaken, it was a miracle that she was still alive. Besides, she herself had lied about who she was, when first meeting Perrin.

ɪn tʃɹuθ, hɝ æŋɡɝ wɑz kəz mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz gɑnə dʒʌdʒ pɛɹɪn. ʃi pɹəzum tə dʒʌdʒ pɛɹɪn.

In truth, her anger was because Morgase was going to judge Perrin. She presumed to judge Perrin.

meɪaɪɡdɪn ðə leɪɾiz meɪd maɪt bi ɡɹeɪtfəl, bʌt mɔɹɡeɪs ðə kwin wəd si pɛɹɪn əz ə ɹaɪvəl.

Maighdin the lady's maid might be grateful, but Morgase the Queen would see Perrin as a rival.

wəd mɔɹɡeɪs ɹɪli tʃɹit ðɪs dʒʌdʒmən fɛɹli, əɹ wəd ʃi teɪk ðə tʃæns tə dɪskɹɛɾət ə mæn u hæd ɹeɪz hɪmsɛlf ʌp əz ə lɔɹd?

Would Morgase really treat this judgment fairly, or would she take the chance to discredit a man who had raised himself up as a lord?

"aɪ fil əz jə du, maɪ leɪɾi," æliændɝ sɛd sɔfli.

"I feel as you do, my Lady," Alliandre said softly.

"æn haʊ ɪz ðæt?"

"And how is that?"

"dɪsivd," æliændɝ sɛd. "meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz əɹ fɹɛnd. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ nu hɝ."

"Deceived," Alliandre said. "Maighdin was our friend. I thought I knew her."

"ju wʊɾə æktəɾ ɪɡzækli əz ʃi dɪɾ ɪn ðət sɪtʃueɪʃən," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "waɪ ɡɪv əweɪ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪf jə doʊn əv tə?"

"You would have acted exactly as she did in that situation," Berelain said. "Why give away information if you don't have to?"

"bɪkɔz wi wɝ fɹɛnz," æliændɝ sɛd. "æftɝ wʌt wi wɛn θɹu təɡɛðɝ, ɪt tɝnz aʊt ðət ʃiz mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd. nɑt dʒʌst ə kwin - ðə kwin. ðə wʊmənz ə lɛdʒənd. ən ʃi wɑz hɪɹ, wɪð ʌs, sɝvɪŋ əs ti. pʊɹli."

"Because we were friends," Alliandre said. "After what we went through together, it turns out that she's Morgase Trakand. Not just a queen - the Queen. The woman's a legend. And she was here, with us, serving us tea. Poorly."

"ju hæv tə ədmɪt," feɪl sɛd θɔtfəli, "ʃi dɪd ɡɛt bɛɾɝ wɪð ðə ti."

"You have to admit," Faile said thoughtfully, "she did get better with the tea."

feɪl ɹitʃt tə hɝ θɹoʊt, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə kɔɹd ðət bɔɹ ɹoʊlənz stoʊn. ʃi dɪdnt wɛɹ ɪɾ ɛvɹi deɪ, bʌt ʃi dɪd soʊ ɔfən ɪnʌf. hæd mɔɹɡeɪs bɪn fɔls ðəɾ ɪntaɪɝ taɪm ðeɪd bɪn wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ? əɹ hæd ʃi, ɪn ə weɪ, bɪn mɔɹ tʃɹu? wɪð noʊ taɪɾəlz tə lɪv ʌp tə, ʃi hædn bɪn fɔɹs tə bi ðə "lɛdʒəndɛɹi" mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd. ʌndɝ sɝkəmstænsəz laɪk ðæt, wʊdn ə pɝsənz tʃɹu neɪtʃɝ bi mɔɹ laɪkli tə ʃoʊ θɹu?

Faile reached to her throat, touching the cord that bore Rolan's stone. She didn't wear it every day, but she did so often enough. Had Morgase been false that entire time they'd been with the Shaido? Or had she, in a way, been more true? With no titles to live up to, she hadn't been forced to be the "legendary" Morgase Trakand. Under circumstances like that, wouldn't a person's true nature be more likely to show through?

feɪl ɡɹɪp ðə kɔɹd. mɔɹɡeɪs wəd nɑt tɝn ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl əɡɛns pɝ-ɹɪn aʊɾ ə spaɪt. bʌt ʃi wəɾ ɔfɝ dʒʌdʒmən ɪn ɑnəsti. wɪtʃ mɛn feɪl niɾəd tə bi pɹipɛɹd, ən əv ɹɛɾi -  skɹimz saʊndəd nɪɹbaɪ.

Faile gripped the cord. Morgase would not turn this trial against Per-rin out of spite. But she would offer judgment in honesty. Which meant Faile needed to be prepared, and have ready -  Screams sounded nearby.

feɪl ɹiæktəɾ ɪmiɾiətli, spɪnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə wʊdz. ʃi ɪnstɪŋktɪvli æntɪsəpeɪɾəd il lipɪŋ fɹəm ðə bʊʃəz tə kɪl ən kæptʃɝ, ən ʃi fɛlt ə moʊmən ə ʃɪɹ pænɪk.

Faile reacted immediately, spinning toward the woods. She instinctively anticipated Aiel leaping from the bushes to kill and capture, and she felt a moment of sheer panic.

bʌt ðə skɹimz wɝ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɪnsaɪd kæmp. ʃi kɝst, tɝnɪŋ əbaʊt, bʌt fɛl sʌmθɪŋ tʌɡ əɾ əɹ bɛlt. ʃi lʊk daʊn wɪð ə stɑɹt tə si hɝ bɛl naɪf pʊl ɪtsɛlf fɹəm ɪts ʃiθ ən flɪp ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

But the screams were coming from inside camp. She cursed, turning about, but felt something tug at her belt. She looked down with a start to see her belt knife pull itself from its sheath and flip into the air.

"ə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl!" bɹəleɪn sɛd, stʌmbəlɪŋ tə ðə saɪd.

"A bubble of evil!" Berelain said, stumbling to the side.

feɪl dʌkt, θɹoʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ðə ɡɹaʊn əz əɹ naɪf nɪp θɹu ði ɛɹ təwɔɹɾ əɹ hɛd.

Faile ducked, throwing herself to the ground as her knife nipped through the air toward her head.

ɪt nɛɹoʊli mɪst. əz feɪl keɪm ʌp ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ, ʃi sɔ wɪð ə stɑɹt ðət bɹəleɪn wɑz feɪsɪŋ daʊn ə dæɡɝ, wʌn ðət lʊkt - fɹəm ðə dæmədʒ tə bɹəleɪnz ʃɝt - tə hæv ɹɪpt ɪts weɪ fɹi ʌv ə hɪɾən ʃiθ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ sliv.

It narrowly missed. As Faile came up in a crouch, she saw with a start that Berelain was facing down a dagger, one that looked - from the damage to Berelain's shirt - to have ripped its way free of a hidden sheath inside her sleeve.

bɪɑn bɹəleɪn, ðə kæmp wɑz ɪn ə tuməlt. ðə nɪɹbaɪ pɹæktəsɪŋ ɹɛfjuɡis wɝ skæɾɝɪŋ, sɔɹdz ən spɪɹz nɪpɪŋ θɹu ði ɛɹ ə ðɛɹ oʊn voʊlɪʃən. ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ɛvɹi wɛpən ɪn ðə kæmp hæd sʌɾənli spɹʌŋ tə laɪf, ɹaɪzɪŋ ʌp tə ətæk ɪts mæstɝ.

Beyond Berelain, the camp was in a tumult. The nearby practicing refugeess were scattering, swords and spears nipping through the air of their own volition. It looked as if every weapon in the camp had suddenly sprung to life, rising up to attack its master.

moʊʃən. feɪl dɑdʒ tə ðə saɪɾ əz əɹ naɪf keɪm bæk fəɹ hɝ, bʌɾ ə waɪt-hɛɹd fɪɡjɝ ɪn bɹaʊn snætʃt ðə wɛpən fɹəm ði ɛɹ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ə taɪt ɡɹɪp. səlɪn ɹoʊld, klɪŋɪŋ tə ɪt, hɝ tiθ ɡɹɪɾɪd əz ʃi ɹɛntʃt ɪt fɹəm ði ɛɹ ən slæmd ɪt daʊn ɑntu ə stoʊn, bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə bleɪd fɹəm ðə hɪlt.

Motion. Faile dodged to the side as her knife came back for her, but a white-haired figure in brown snatched the weapon from the air, holding it in a tight grip. Sulin rolled, clinging to it, her teeth gritted as she wrenched it from the air and slammed it down onto a stone, breaking the blade from the hilt.

ɪt stɑp muvɪŋ. səlɪnz spɪɹz, haʊɛvɝ, pʊl fɹəm ðɛɹ pleɪs ɑn əɹ bæk ən spʌn ɪn ðə skaɪ, tɪps pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ.

It stopped moving. Sulin's spears, however, pulled from their place on her back and spun in the sky, tips pointing toward her.

"ɹʌn!" ðə meɪɾən sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə feɪs ɔl θɹi spɪɹz ət wʌns.

"Run!" the Maiden said, turning and trying to face all three spears at once.

"wɛɹ?" feɪl dɪmændəd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ə stoʊn fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "ðə wɛpənz ɑɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ."

"Where?" Faile demanded, picking up a stone from the ground. "The weapons are everywhere."

bɹəleɪn wɑz stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð əɹ dæɡɝ. ʃid ɡɹæbd ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz faɪɾɪŋ hɝ, ɹɛntʃɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd. æliændɝ wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ θɹi naɪvz. laɪt! feɪl sʌɾənli fɛlt lʌki fəɹ hævɪŋ wɔɹn oʊnli wʌn tədeɪ.

Berelain was struggling with her dagger. She'd grabbed it, but it was fighting her, wrenching her arms from side to side. Alliandre was surrounded by three knives. Light! Faile suddenly felt lucky for having worn only one today.

sɛvɹəl ə ðə meɪɾənz tʃɑɹdʒd ɪn tə hɛlp æliændɝ, θɹoʊɪŋ stoʊnz ət ðə naɪvz, dɑdʒɪŋ spɪɹz ðət lʌnʒd fəɹ ðɛm. bɹəleɪn wɑz əloʊn.

Several of the Maidens charged in to help Alliandre, throwing stones at the knives, dodging spears that lunged for them. Berelain was alone.

ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ - filɪŋ hæf ə ful fəɹ hɛlpɪŋ ðə wʊmən ʃi heɪɾəd - feɪl dʒʌmpt ɪn ən pleɪst əɹ hænz oʊvɝ bɹəleɪnz, lɛndɪŋ əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ tə ðəɾ ə ðə fɝst. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ ɹɛntʃt ðə dæɡɝ tə ðə saɪd, təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd dʒɹaɪv ɪts pɔɪn ɪndə ði ɝθ. wən ðeɪ dɪd, ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, ɪt stɑp muvɪŋ.

Gritting her teeth - feeling half a fool for helping the woman she hated - Faile jumped in and placed her hands over Berelain's, lending her strength to that of the First. Together, they wrenched the dagger to the side, toward the ground, where they could drive its point into the earth. When they did, remarkably, it stopped moving.

feɪl ɹilist ɪt hɛzɪɾəntli, ðən lʊkt ʌp ət ðə dɪʃɛvəl bɹəleɪn. ðə wʊmən pɹɛst əɹ ɹaɪt hæn tə hɝ ʌðɝ pɑm, stæntʃɪŋ ðə blʌd fɹəm ə kʌt ʃid teɪkən. ʃi nɑɾəd ət feɪl. "θæŋk ju."

Faile released it hesitantly, then looked up at the disheveled Berelain. The woman pressed her right hand to her other palm, stanching the blood from a cut she'd taken. She nodded at Faile. "Thank you."

"wʌt stɑpt ɪt?" feɪl æskt, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ. ʃaʊts saʊndəd fɹəm ɝaʊn ðə kæmp. kɝsɪŋ.

"What stopped it?" Faile asked, heart thumping. Shouts sounded from around the camp. Cursing.

klæŋz fɹəm wɛpənz.

Clangs from weapons.

"ðə dɝt?" bɹəleɪn æskt, nilɪŋ.

"The dirt?" Berelain asked, kneeling.

feɪl dʌɡ hɝ fɪŋɡɝz ɪndə ðə loʊm. ʃi tɝnd, noʊɾɪsɪŋ wɪð əlɑɹm ðət wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz wɑz daʊn, ðoʊ ʌðɝz hæd fɛl sɛvɹəl ə ðə flaɪɪŋ spɪɹz. feɪl tɔst əɹ hændfʊl ə sɔɪl ət wʌn ðət wɑz stɪl wɪpɪŋ əbaʊt.

Faile dug her fingers into the loam. She turned, noticing with alarm that one of the Maidens was down, though others had felled several of the flying spears. Faile tossed her handful of soil at one that was still whipping about.

wən ðə dɝt tʌtʃt ðə spɪɹ, ðə wɛpən dʒɹɑpt. səlɪn sɔ ɪt, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ bɪhaɪn əɹ veɪl feɪs. ʃi dʒɹɑp ðə stoʊnz ʃid bɪn wildɪŋ ən tʊk ʌp ə hændfʊl ə sɔɪl, spɹeɪɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛɾ əz ə spɪɹ dʒɹoʊv fəɹ əɹ hɑɹt.

When the dirt touched the spear, the weapon dropped. Sulin saw it, eyes widening behind her veiled face. She dropped the stones she'd been wielding and took up a handful of soil, spraying it over her head as a spear drove for her heart.

ðə dɝt stɑpt ɪt, ən ɪt fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nɪɹbaɪ, ðə soʊlʒɝz u hæd bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ əlɔŋ tə ɡɑɹd feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ hævɪŋ ə wɝs taɪm ə θɪŋz. ðeɪ hæd bækt ɪndə ə sɝkəl, juzɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃilz tə blɑk ɪnkʌmɪŋ wɛpənz, hʌŋkɝd daʊn wɪð wɝiɾ ɪkspɹɛʃənz.

The dirt stopped it, and it fell to the ground. Nearby, the soldiers who had been following along to guard Faile and the others were having a worse time of things. They had backed into a circle, using their shields to block incoming weapons, hunkered down with worried expressions.

"kwɪkli!" feɪl sɛd tə ðə meɪɾənz, dɪɡɪŋ boʊθ hænz ɪndə ðə sɔɪl. "spɹɛd ðə wɝd! lɛt ði ʌðɝz noʊ haʊ tə stɑp ðə wɛpənz!" ʃi θɹu sɔɪl ət ðə dæɡɝz bɪsaɪɾ æliændɝ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ tu wɪð wʌn θɹoʊ, ðən bɪɡæn ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə nɪɹbaɪ soʊlʒɝz.

"Quickly!" Faile said to the Maidens, digging both hands into the soil. "Spread the word! Let the others know how to stop the weapons!" She threw soil at the daggers beside Alliandre, dropping two with one throw, then began running for the nearby soldiers.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə əpɑlədʒaɪz, ɡɑləd," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd sɔfli. "ju kʊdn əv noʊn wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪt. jə wɝ liɡz ən liɡz əweɪ."

"There is no need for you to apologize, Galad," Morgase said softly. "You couldn't have known what was happening in the Fortress of the Light. You were leagues and leagues away."

ðeɪ sæɾ ɪn ɪz tɛnt, tʃɛɹz feɪsɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ, leɪt-æftɝnun laɪt ʃaɪnɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz. ɡɑləd sæt wɪð hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ ɪm əz i lin fɔɹwɝd. soʊ θɔtfəl. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ fɝst ɪmpɹɛʃənz ə hɪm, lɔŋ əɡoʊ wən ʃid mɛɹiɾ ɪz fɑðɝ. ðə jʌŋ tʃaɪl hæd sɪmpli bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ðə dil, ən waɪl mɔɹɡeɪs hæɾ ədɑptəd hɪm, ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz wɝid ðəɾ i fɛlt lɛs lʌv ðən ɪz sɪblɪŋz.

They sat in his tent, chairs facing each other, late-afternoon light shining on the walls. Galad sat with hands clasped before him as he leaned forward. So thoughtful. She remembered her first impressions of him, long ago when she'd married his father. The young child had simply been part of the deal, and while Morgase had adopted him, she had always worried that he felt less loved than his siblings.

ɡɑləd hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn soʊ sɑləm. kwɪk tə pɔɪn aʊt wən sʌmwʌn dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. bʌɾ ənlaɪk ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən - ɪleɪn ɪspɛʃli - hi hæd nɑt juzd ɪz nɑlədʒ əz ə wɛpən. ʃi ʃəɾ əv sin. ʃi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪz hid bi ətʃɹæktəd tə ðə waɪtkloʊks fəɹ ðɛɹ vɪʒən ʌv ə wɝl ðət wɑz blæk ən waɪt. kəd ʃi hæv pɹipɛɹɾ ɪm bɛɾɝ? ʃoʊn ɪm ðət ðə wɝld wɑz nɑt blæk ən waɪt - ɪt wɑzn ivən ɡɹeɪ. ɪt wɑz fʊl ə kʌlɝz ðət səmtaɪmz dɪdn fɪɾ ɪndə ɛni spɛktʃɹəm ə mɝæləɾi.

Galad had always been so solemn. Quick to point out when someone did something wrong. But unlike other children - Elayne especially - he had not used his knowledge as a weapon. She should have seen. She should have realized he'd be attracted to the Whitecloaks for their vision of a world that was black and white. Could she have prepared him better? Shown him that the world was not black and white - it wasn't even gray. It was full of colors that sometimes didn't fit into any spectrum of morality.

hi lʊkt ʌp, hænz stɪl klæspt, aɪz tʃɹʌbəld. "aɪ əkjuz vɑldə ɹɔŋli. wən aɪ wɛn tə hɪm, aɪ sɛɾ aɪ wɑz dɪmændɪŋ tʃɹaɪəl bɪniθ ðə laɪt kəz i hæɾ əbjuz jə ən kɪl ju. hæf wɑz ɹɔŋ. aɪ hæv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ wɛɹ aɪ wɑz ɪn ɛɹɝ, ət list ɪn pɑɹt. ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðət fækt, aɪm pliz ðəɾ aɪ kɪl hɪm."

He looked up, hands still clasped, eyes troubled. "I accused Valda wrongly. When I went to him, I said I was demanding Trial Beneath the Light because he had abused you and killed you. Half was wrong. I have done something where I was in error, at least in part. Regardless of that fact, I'm pleased that I killed him."

hɝ bɹɛθ kɑɾ ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. vɑldə hæd ɹɪpjuɾɪdli bɪn wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɔɝdzmɪn əlaɪv.

Her breath caught in her throat. Valda had reputedly been one of the greatest swordsmen alive.

ən ɡɑləd hæd bɛstɪɾ ɪm ɪn ə duəl? ðɪs juθ? bʌɾ i wɑz ə juθ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. ɡɑləd hæd meɪɾ ɪz tʃɔɪsəz, ən ʃi hæɾ ə dɪfəkəl taɪm dʒʌdʒɪŋ ɪm fəɹ ðɛm. ɪn səm weɪz, ðeɪ simd mɔɹ ædmɝəbəl ðən əɹ oʊn tʃɔɪsəz.

And Galad had bested him in a duel? This youth? But he was a youth no longer. Galad had made his choices, and she had a difficult time judging him for them. In some ways, they seemed more admirable than her own choices.

"ju dɪd wɛl," ʃi sɛd. "vɑldə wɑz ə sneɪk. aɪm sɝɾən i wɑz bɪhaɪnd naɪlz dɛθ. ɡɑləd, jə dɪd ðə wɝld ə sɝvəs."

"You did well," she said. "Valda was a snake. I am certain he was behind Niall's death. Galad, you did the world a service."

hi nɑɾəd. "fɔɹ wʌɾ i dɪd tə ju, hi dɪzɝv dɛθ. bʌɾ aɪ ʃæl nid tə ɹilis ə steɪtmən ɛniweɪ." hi ɹoʊz, klæspɪŋ ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əz i wɔkt, hɪz waɪt kloʊðɪŋ simɪŋ tə ɡloʊ ɪn ðə laɪt. "aɪ wɪl ɪkspleɪn ðət maɪ ækjəzeɪʃən ə mɝɾɝ wɑz fɔls, bʌt ðət vɑldə stɪl dɪzɝv dɛθ fəɹ ɪz ʌðɝ əfɛnsɪz. daɪɹ əfɛnsɪz." hi stɑp fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ hæd noʊn."

He nodded. "For what he did to you, he deserved death. But I shall need to release a statement anyway." He rose, clasping his hands behind his back as he walked, his white clothing seeming to glow in the light. "I will explain that my accusation of murder was false, but that Valda still deserved death for his other offenses. Dire offenses." He stopped for a moment. "I wish I had known."

"ðɛɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ jə kəɾ əv dʌn, sʌn," ʃi sɛd. "maɪ kæptɪvəɾi wɑz maɪ oʊn fɔlt. fəɹ tʃɹʌstɪŋ maɪ ɛnəmiz."

"There was nothing you could have done, son," she said. "My captivity was my own fault. For trusting my enemies."

ɡɑləd weɪvd ə hænd. "ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ɡeɪbɹəl, ɪf wʌt juv hɝɾ ɪz tʃɹu. əz fəɹ jəɹ kæptɪvəɾi, jə dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs jəɹ ɛnəmiz. jə wɝ bɪtʃɹeɪd, laɪk ɔl ʌv ʌs, baɪ vɑldə. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ nɛvɝ ði ɛnəmiz ʌv ə pɝsən u wɔks ɪn ðə laɪt."

Galad waved a hand. "There was no resisting Gaebril, if what you have heard is true. As for your captivity, you did not trust your enemies. You were betrayed, like all of us, by Valda. The Children are never the enemies of a person who walks in the Light."

"æn pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?" ʃi æskt.

"And Perrin Aybara?" she asked.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn."

"Shadowspawn."

"noʊ, sʌn. aɪ doʊn laɪk səm ə ðə θɪŋz hiz duɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməs ju, hiz ə ɡʊd mæn."

"No, son. I don't like some of the things he is doing, but I promise you, he is a good man."

"ðɛn ðə tʃɹaɪəl wɪl pɹuv ðæt," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"Then the trial will prove that," Galad said.

"ɡʊd mɛn kən meɪk mɪsteɪks. ɪf jə pɹoʊsid wɪð ðɪs, ɪt kəɾ ɛn ɪn ə weɪ ðət nʌn ʌv əs wɪʃ."

"Good men can make mistakes. If you proceed with this, it could end in a way that none of us wish."

ɡɑləd fɹoʊz, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "mʌðɝ, ɑɹ jə ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðəɾ i ʃəd bi əlaʊd tə ɪskeɪp ɪz kɹaɪm?"

Galad froze, frowning. "Mother, are you implying that he should be allowed to escape his crime?"

"kʌm," ʃi sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ. "sɪt bæk daʊn. jəɹ dɪziɪŋ mi wɪð ðət peɪsɪŋ əbaʊt."

"Come," she said, gesturing. "Sit back down. You're dizzying me with that pacing about."

pɝhæps hid ɹɪzən tə ðə pəzɪʃən ə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ oʊnli ɹisənli, bʌɾ i ɔlɹɛɾi sim tə bɹɪsəl ət teɪkɪŋ ən ɔɹɾɝ. hi dɪd sɪt, haʊɛvɝ.

Perhaps he'd risen to the position of Lord Captain Commander only recently, but he already seemed to bristle at taking an order. He did sit, however.

ɑdli, ʃi fɛlt laɪk ə kwin əɡɛn. ɡɑləd hædn sin əɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə hɑɹd mʌnθs. hi θɔɾ ə hɝ əz ði oʊl mɔɹɡeɪs, soʊ ɝaʊn hɪm, ʃi æktʃəli  fɛlt laɪk ði oʊl mɔɹɡeɪs. ɔlmoʊst.

Oddly, she felt like a queen again. Galad hadn't seen her during the hard months. He thought of her as the old Morgase, so around him, she actually felt like the old Morgase. Almost.

naɪl hæd hɛld əɹ əz ə pɹɪznɝ, bʌt hæd ɹɪspɛktɪd hɝ, ən ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ðət ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪspɛkt ɪm əz wɛl. wʌt hæd hæpən tə ðə bɔɹd wɛɹ ʃi ən naɪl hæd pleɪd stoʊnz soʊ ɔfən? ʃi heɪɾəd tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt bɹoʊkən ɪn ðə sintʃæn əsɔlt.

Niall had held her as a prisoner, but had respected her, and she had begun to think that she might be able to respect him as well. What had happened to the board where she and Niall had played stones so often? She hated to think of it broken in the Seanchan assault.

wəd ɡɑləd bɪkʌm ə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ laɪk naɪl, əɹ pɝhæps sʌmwʌn bɛɾɝ? ðə kwin ɪn hɝ, ðə kwin ɹiəweɪkənd, wɑntəd tə faɪn ə weɪ tə bɹɪŋ ɪz laɪɾ aʊɾ ən staɪfəl ðə ʃædoʊ.

Would Galad become a Lord Captain Commander like Niall, or perhaps someone better? The Queen in her, the Queen reawakened, wanted to find a way to bring his light out and stifle the shadow.

"ɡɑləd," ʃi sɛd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

"Galad," she said. "What are you going to do?"

"əbaʊt ðə tʃɹaɪəl?"

"About the trial?"

"noʊ. wɪð ðɪs ɑɹmi ʌv jʊɹz."

"No. With this army of yours."

"wi wɪl faɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl."

"We will fight at the Last Battle."

"ædmɝəbəl," ʃi sɛd. "bʌt dʒju noʊ wʌt ðət minz?"

"Admirable," she said. "But do you know what that means?"

"ɪt minz faɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"It means fighting alongside the Dragon Reborn."

"æn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"And the Aes Sedai."

"wi kən sɝv əlɔŋsaɪd ðə wɪtʃəz fəɹ ə taɪm, ɪf ɪts ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɡʊd."

"We can serve alongside the witches for a time, if it is in the name of the greater good."

ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, bɹiðɪŋ aʊt. "ɡɑləd, lɪsən tə jɝsɛlf. jə neɪm əm wɪtʃəz? jə wɛn tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð ðɛm, pɝhæps tə bɪkʌm ə wɔɹɾɝ!"

She closed her eyes, breathing out. "Galad, listen to yourself. You name them witches? You went to train with them, perhaps to become a Warder!"

"jɛs."

"Yes."

ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz. hi sim soʊ ɝnɪst. bʌɾ ivən ðə moʊs dɛdli ən vaɪələn ə haʊnz kəd bi ɝnɪst. "du jə noʊ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd tə ɪleɪn, mʌðɝ?" hi æskt.

She opened her eyes. He seemed so earnest. But even the most deadly and violent of hounds could be earnest. "Do you know what they did to Elayne, Mother?" he asked.

"ju min luzɪŋ hɝ?" mɔɹɡeɪs stɪl hɑɹbɝɾ æŋɡɝ oʊvɝ ðæt.

"You mean losing her?" Morgase still harbored anger over that.

"ðeɪ sɛn əɹ aʊɾ ɑn mɪʃənz," hi sɛd, vɔɪs leɪst wɪð dɪsɡʌst. '"ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə lemi si hɝ, pɹɑbli kəz ʃi wɑz aʊt biɪŋ pʊɾ ɪndə deɪnʒɝ. aɪ mɛɾ əɹ leɪɾɝ, aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ."

"They sent her out on missions," he said, voice laced with disgust. '"They refused to let me see her, probably because she was out being put into danger. I met her later, outside the Tower."

"wɛɹ wɑz ʃi?" mɔɹɡeɪs æskt, iɡɝ.

"Where was she?" Morgase asked, eager.

"hɪɹ ɪn ðə saʊθ. maɪ mɛn neɪm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪtʃəz. səmtaɪmz, aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ fɑɹ ɔf fɹəm ðə tʃɹuθ ðəɾ ɪz."

"Here in the south. My men name the Aes Sedai witches. Sometimes, I wonder how far off from the truth that is."

"ɡɑləd . . ."

"Galad . . ."

"nɑɾ ɔl wɪmən u wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɑɹ ivəl ɪnhɪɹənli," hi sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz ə mɪsteɪkən tʃɹədɪʃən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə weɪ ʌv ðə laɪt dʌzn meɪk ðət kleɪm; ɪt dʒʌst sɛz ðət ðə tɛmteɪʃən tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən kɝʌpt. aɪ bɪliv ðət ðə wɪmən u naʊ ɹʌn ðə waɪt taʊɝ əv lɛt ðɛɹ skimz ən sɛlfɪʃ plɑts blaɪn ðɛm."

"Not all women who wield the One Power are evil inherently," he said. "That is a mistaken tradition of the Children. The Way of the Light doesn't make that claim; it just says that the temptation to use the One Power can corrupt. I believe that the women who now run the White Tower have let their schemes and selfish plots blind them."

ʃi nɑɾəd, nɑt wɪʃɪŋ tə ɑɹɡju ðə pɔɪnt. θæŋk ðə laɪɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑzn hɪɹ tə hɪɹ ðət lɑdʒɪk!

She nodded, not wishing to argue the point. Thank the Light Elaida wasn't here to hear that logic!

"iðɝ weɪ," hi sɛd. "wi wɪl faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðɛm, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ðɪs pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə ɪf nid bi. ðə stʃɹʌɡəl əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ aʊtweɪz ɔl ʌðɝ kənsɝnz."

"Either way," he said. "We will fight alongside them, and the Dragon Reborn, and this Perrin Aybara if need be. The struggle against the Shadow outweighs all other concerns."

"ðɛn lɛɾ əs dʒɔɪn ðət stʃɹʌɡəl," ʃi sɛd. "ɡɑləd, fɝɡɛt ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl! eɪbɑɹə ɪntɛnz tə dɪsbæn səm ə hɪz ɑɹmi ən ɡɪv ðə ɹɛs tə ælθɹ."

"Then let us join that struggle," she said. "Galad, forget this trial! Aybara intends to disband some of his army and give the rest to al'Thor."

hi mɛɾ əɹ aɪz, ðən nɑɾəd. "jɛs. aɪ kən si naʊ ðət ðə pæɾɝn əz lɛd jə tə mi. wɪl tʃɹævəl wɪð ju. æftɝ ðə tʃɹaɪəl əz fɪnɪʃt."

He met her eyes, then nodded. "Yes. I can see now that the Pattern has led you to me. We will travel with you. After the trial has finished."

ʃi saɪd.

She sighed.

"aɪ doʊn də ðɪs baɪ tʃɔɪs," ɡɑləd sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ əɡɛn. "eɪbɑɹə hɪmsɛlf sədʒɛstəd ðəɾ i bi tʃɹaɪd.

"I don't do this by choice," Galad said, rising again. "Aybara himself suggested that he be tried.

ðə mænz kɑnʃəns weɪz əɡɛns hɪm, ən tə dɪnaɪ hɪm ðɪs ɑpɝtunəɾi wəd bi ɹɔŋ. lɛɾ ɪm pɹuv ɪz ɪnəsəns tə ʌs, ən tə hɪmsɛlf. ðən wi kən kəntɪnju." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɹitʃɪŋ aʊɾ ən tʌtʃɪŋ ðə waɪt-skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz dʒɹɛsɪŋ teɪbəl. "æn ɪf wi kəntɪnju wɪθaʊt hɪm, ðən hɪl ɹɛst ɪn ðə laɪt, hævɪŋ peɪd fəɹ ɪz kɹaɪmz." ɡɑləd," ʃi sɛd, "ju noʊ lini wɑz əmʌŋ ðə pipəl jə tʊk fɹəm pɛɹɪnz kæmp."

The man's conscience weighs against him, and to deny him this opportunity would be wrong. Let him prove his innocence to us, and to himself. Then we can continue." He hesitated, reaching out and touching the white-scabbarded sword on his dressing table. "And if we continue without him, then he will rest in the Light, having paid for his crimes." Galad," she said, "you know Lini was among the people you took from Perrin's camp."

ʃi ʃʊɾə spoʊkən ʌp, ɹɪvil hɝsɛlf tə mi. aɪ wʊɾə sɛɾ əɹ fɹi."

She should have spoken up, revealed herself to me. I would have set her free."

ən jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑt. aɪ hæv hɝd jə ɔl bʌt θɹɛɾənd tə ɛksəkjut ðə pɹɪznɝz ɪf pɛɹɪn dɪdn kʌm tə bæɾəl. wəd juv æktʃəli  dʌn ðɪs?" ðɛɹ wʊɾə əv bɪn ɑn ɪz hɛd."

And yet she did not. I have heard you all but threatened to execute the prisoners if Perrin didn't come to battle. Would you have actually done this?" Their blood would have been on his head."

"liniz blʌd, ɡɑləd?"

"Lini's blood, Galad?"

"aɪ... aɪ wʊɾə sin əɹ əmʌŋ əm ən ɹimuvd əɹ fɹəm deɪnʒɝ.".

"I... I would have seen her among them and removed her from danger.".

"soʊ jə wʊɾə kɪl ði ʌðɝz," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "pipəl u dɪd noʊ ɹɔŋ, hu wɝ ɪnəsən ə nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən biɪŋ bɪɡaɪl baɪ eɪbɑɹə?"

"So you would have killed the others," Morgase said. "People who did no wrong, who were innocent of nothing more than being beguiled by Aybara?"

"ði ɛksəkjuʃənz wəd nɛvɝ əv əkɝd. ɪt wɑz mɪɹli ə θɹɛt"

"The executions would never have occurred. It was merely a threat"

"ə laɪ."

"A lie."

"bɑ! wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɔɪn ə ðɪs, mʌðɝ?"

"Bah! What is the point of this, Mother?"

"tə meɪk jə θɪŋk, sʌn," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "ɪn weɪz ðəɾ aɪ ʃʊɾə ɛnkɝɪdʒ bɪfɔɹ, ɹæðɝ ðən livɪŋ jə tə jəɹ sɪmpəl ɪluʒənz. laɪf ɪz nɑt soʊ izi əz ðə tɔs ʌv ə kɔɪn, wʌn saɪɾ əɹ ði ʌðɝ. hæv aɪ ɛvɝ toʊl jə ʌv ðə tʃɹaɪəl ə θæm fɛlmli?"

"To make you think, son," Morgase said. "In ways that I should have encouraged before, rather than leaving you to your simple illusions. Life is not so easy as the toss of a coin, one side or the other. Have I ever told you of the trial of Tham Felmley?"

ɡɑləd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, lʊkɪŋ ɪɹəteɪɾəd.

Galad shook his head, looking irritated.

"lɪsən tə mi. hi wɑz ə bɹɪkmeɪsən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ə ɹɛpjəɾəbəl wʌn. hi wɑz əkjuzd ə mɝɾɝɪŋ ɪz bɹʌðɝ ɪn ði ɝli deɪz ə maɪ ɹeɪn. hi hæɾ ɪnʌf ɹipjut, ən ðə keɪs wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf, ðəɾ aɪ dʒʌdʒd ɪt maɪsɛlf. hi hæŋd ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪt."

"Listen to me. He was a brickmason in Caemlyn, a reputable one. He was accused of murdering his brother in the early days of my reign. He had enough repute, and the case was important enough, that I judged it myself. He hanged at the end of it."

"ə fɪɾɪŋ ɛn fəɹ ə mɝɾɝɝ."

"A fitting end for a murderer."

"jɛs," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə mɝɾɝɝ wɛn fɹi. wʌn ə hɪz wɝkɝz hæɾ æktʃəli  dʌn ðə did. ɪt dɪdn kʌm aʊɾ əntɪl tu jɪɹz leɪɾɝ, wən ðə mæn wɑz teɪkən fəɹ ənʌðɝ mɝɾɝ. hi læft əɾ əs ðɛn, əz wi hæŋ hɪm. fɛlmli hæd bɪn ɪnəsən ɔl əlɔŋ. ðə ɹil mæn, ðə mɝɾɝɝ, wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz tə kəndɛm ɪm dʊɹɪŋ ði ɝɪdʒənəl tʃɹaɪəl."

"Yes," Morgase said. "Unfortunately, the murderer went free. One of his workers had actually done the deed. It didn't come out until two years later, when the man was taken for another murder. He laughed at us then, as we hanged him. Felmley had been innocent all along. The real man, the murderer, was one of those to condemn him during the original trial."

ɡɑləd fɛl saɪlənt.

Galad fell silent.

"ɪts ði oʊnli taɪm," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd, "wɛɹ aɪ noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən ðəɾ aɪ hæŋ sʌmwʌn baɪ mɪsteɪk. soʊ jə tɛl mi, ɡɑləd. ʃəɾ aɪ hæŋ fəɹ maɪ mɪsteɪk ɪn kəndɛmɪŋ ən ɪnəsən mæn?"

"It's the only time," Morgase said, "where I know for certain that I hanged someone by mistake. So you tell me, Galad. Should I hang for my mistake in condemning an innocent man?"

"ju dɪd jəɹ bɛst, mʌðɝ."

"You did your best, Mother."

"æn ə mæn ɪz stɪl dɛɾ u dɪd nɑt dɪzɝv ɪt."

"And a man is still dead who did not deserve it."

ɡɑləd lʊk tʃɹʌbəld.

Galad looked troubled.

"ðə tʃɪlʒɹən laɪk tə spik ə ðə laɪt pɹətɛktɪŋ ðɛm," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd, "ʌv ɡaɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ dʒʌdʒmən ən liɾɪŋ pipəl tə dʒʌstəs. ðəɾ ɪzən haʊ ɪt wɝks, ɡɑləd. vɑldə, kleɪmɪŋ ðə blɛsɪŋ ə ðə laɪt, kəd də tɛɹəbəl θɪŋz. ən aɪ, hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ðə laɪts eɪd, hæv kɪld əndʒʌsli.

"The Children like to speak of the Light protecting them," Morgase said, "of guiding their judgment and leading people to justice. That isn't how it works, Galad. Valda, claiming the blessing of the Light, could do terrible things. And I, hoping for the Light's aid, have killed unjustly.

"aɪm nɑt seɪɪŋ ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə ɪz ɪnəsənt. aɪ hævən hɝɾ ɪnʌf iðɝ weɪ. bʌɾ aɪ wɑn jə tə ʌndɝstænd. səmtaɪmz ə ɡʊd mæn kən də ɹɔŋ. ət taɪmz, ɪts əpɹoʊpɹiət tə pʌnɪʃ hɪm. əɾ ʌðɝ taɪmz, pʌnɪʃmən sɝvz noʊbɑdi, ən ðə bɛs θɪŋ tə də ɪz tə lɛɾ ɪm kəntɪnju ən lɝn. əz aɪ kəntɪnjuɾ ən lɝnd, æftɝ meɪkɪŋ sətʃ ə pʊɹ dʒʌdʒmənt."

"I'm not saying that Aybara is innocent. I haven't heard enough either way. But I want you to understand. Sometimes a good man can do wrong. At times, it is appropriate to punish him. At other times, punishment serves nobody, and the best thing to do is to let him continue and learn. As I continued and learned, after making such a poor judgment."

ɡɑləd fɹaʊnd. ðət wɑz ɡʊd. faɪnəli, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, hɪz feɪs klɪɹɪŋ. "wi ʃæl si wʌt ðə tʃɹaɪəl bɹɪŋz. ɪt - "

Galad frowned. That was good. Finally, he shook his head, his face clearing. "We shall see what the trial brings. It - "

ðəɹ wɑz ə nɑk ɑn ðə poʊst aʊtsaɪd. ɡɑləd tɝnd, hɪz fɹaʊn dip-ɛnɪŋ. "jɛs?"

There was a knock on the post outside. Galad turned, his frown deep-ening. "Yes?"

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," ə waɪtkloʊk sɛd, lɪftɪŋ ðə næp ændstɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə tɛnt. hi wɑz ə lin mæn wɪð sʌŋkən aɪz ðət hæd dɑɹk pætʃəz bɪniθ ðɛm. "wiv dʒʌs hæd wɝd fɹəm ðə kɹitʃɝ eɪ-bɑɹəz kæmp. ðəɹ æskɪŋ tə pʊʃ bæk ðə deɪ ʌv ðə tʃɹaɪəl."

"My Lord Captain Commander," a Whitecloak said, lifting the nap andstepping into the tent. He was a lean man with sunken eyes that had dark patches beneath them. "We've just had word from the creature Ay-bara's camp. They're asking to push back the day of the trial."

ɡɑləd stʊd. "fɔɹ wʌt pɝpəs?" hi dɪmændəd.

Galad stood. "For what purpose?" he demanded.

"ə dɪstɝbəns ɪn ðɛɹ kæmp, ðeɪ kleɪm," ðə waɪtkloʊk sɛd. "sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt wundəd niɾɪŋ tɛndɪŋ. maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ... ɪts ɑbviəsli ə plɔɪ. ə tʃɹɪk ə səm sɔɹt. wi ʃəɾ ətæk ðɛm, əɹ ət ðə vɛɹi list, dɪnaɪ ðɪs pɔɪnləs ɪkstɛnʃən."

"A disturbance in their camp, they claim," the Whitecloak said. "Something about wounded needing tending. My Lord Captain Commander ... it is obviously a ploy. A trick of some sort. We should attack them, or at the very least, deny this pointless extension."

ɡɑləd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi lʊkt ət mɔɹɡeɪs.

Galad hesitated. He looked at Morgase.

"ɪɾ ɪz noʊ plɔɪ, sʌn," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ kən pɹɑməs jə ðæt. ɪf eɪbɑɹə sɛz i nidz mɔɹ taɪm, hiz biɪŋ ɑnəst wɪð ju."

"It is no ploy, son," she said. "I can promise you that. If Aybara says he needs more time, he's being honest with you."

"bɑ," ɡɑləd sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ðə mɛsənʒɝ əweɪ. "aɪ ʃæl kənsɪɾɝ ɪt. əlɔŋsaɪd ðə θɪŋz juv sɛd, mʌðɝ. pɝhæps səm ɛkstʃɹə taɪm tə kənsɪɾɝ wəd bi . . . wɛlkəmd."

"Bah," Galad said, waving the messenger away. "I shall consider it. Alongside the things you have said, Mother. Perhaps some extra time to consider would be . . . welcomed."

"ðə tʃænlɝz seɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ wɝkɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ kæn," ɡɔl ɪkspleɪnd, wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn ðoʊ kæmp əz ðeɪ tʃɛk ðə vɛɹiəs sɛkʃənz. "bʌt ðeɪ seɪ ɪt kəd teɪk deɪz tə si tə ɛvɹiwʌn."

"The channelers say they are working as hard as they can," Gaul explained, walking beside Perrin though camp as they checked the various sections. "But they say it could take days to see to everyone."
