ðə sʌn wɑz sɪŋkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən, bʌɾ ɪt wəd pɹɑbli bi ə lɔŋ naɪt fəɹ mɛni ʌv ðɛm, tɛndɪŋ ðə wundəd. θaʊzənz hæd bɪn wundəd, ðoʊ moʊst wunz - fɔɹtʃənətli - wɝ nɑt bæd. ðeɪd lɔst səm pipəl. tu mɛni, meɪbi əz mɛni əz hæd fɔlən tə ðə sneɪk baɪts.

The sun was sinking toward the horizon, but it would probably be a long night for many of them, tending the wounded. Thousands had been wounded, though most wounds - fortunately - were not bad. They'd lost some people. Too many, maybe as many as had fallen to the snake bites.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. ɡɔl hɪmsɛlf hæɾ ɪz ɑɹm ɪn ə slɪŋ; hid fɛndɪɾ ɔf ɪz spɪɹz, oʊnli tə hæv wʌn ə hɪz æɹoʊz nɪɹli kɪl hɪm. hid blɑkt ɪt wɪð ɪz fɔɹɑɹm. wən pɛɹɪn hæɾ æskt, hid læft ən sɛd ðəɾ ɪt hæd bɪn jɪɹz sɪns hid ʃɑt hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪz oʊn æɹoʊ. il hjumɝ.

Perrin grunted. Gaul himself had his arm in a sling; he'd fended off his spears, only to have one of his arrows nearly kill him. He'd blocked it with his forearm. When Perrin had asked, he'd laughed and said that it had been years since he'd shot himself with his own arrow. Aiel humor.

"hæv wi hɝd bæk fɹəm ðə waɪtkloʊks?" pɛɹɪn æskt, tɝnɪŋ tə ɝɑvin, hu wɔkt ɑn ɪz ʌðɝ saɪd.

"Have we heard back from the Whitecloaks?" Perrin asked, turning to Aravine, who walked on his other side.

jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "bʌt nʌθɪŋ spəsɪfɪk. ðɛɹ kəmændɝ sɛd hid θɪŋk' əbaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ əs mɔɹ taɪm."

Yes," she said. "But nothing specific. Their commander said he'd think' about giving us more time."

wɛl, hiz nɑt ðə wʌn u wɪl dɪsaɪd," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə minɝ sɛkʃən ə kæmp tə tʃɛk ɑn bɹəleɪnz pipəl. "aɪm nɑt gɑnə ɹɪsk ə bæɾəl wɪð ə kɔɹɾɝ ə maɪ mɛn wundəɾ ən maɪ æʃəmən dɛd taɪɝd fɹəm hilɪŋ. wi ɡoʊ tə ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl wən aɪ seɪ soʊ, ən ɪf dəmədʒɹd dɪsəɡɹiz, hi kən dʒʌst ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən ətæk ʌs."

Well, he's not the one who will decide," Perrin said, going into the Mayener section of camp to check on Berelain's people. "I'm not going to risk a battle with a quarter of my men wounded and my Asha'man dead tired from Healing. We go to this trial when I say so, and if Damodred disagrees, he can just go ahead and attack us."

ɡɔl ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪz əɡɹimənt. hi wɔɹ ɪz spɪɹz, bʌt pɛɹɪn noʊɾəst ðeɪ wɝ stʃɹæp mɔɹ taɪtli ɪn pleɪs ðən juʒəwəl. ɝɑvin kæɹiɾ ə læn-tɝn, ðoʊ ðeɪ hædnt niɾəd tə laɪɾ ɪt jɛt. ʃi wɑz æntɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ ə leɪt naɪɾ əz wɛl.

Gaul grunted his agreement. He wore his spears, but Perrin noticed they were strapped more tightly in place than usual. Aravine carried a lan-tern, though they hadn't needed to light it yet. She was anticipating a late night as well.

"lɛt mi noʊ wən tɑɹn ən ɛlaɪəs ɡɛt bæk," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə ɡɔl. pɛɹɪn hæd sɛn itʃ wʌn sɛpɝətli tə vɪzət nɪɹbaɪ vɪlədʒəz ən meɪk sɝɾən ðə pipəl ðəɹ - ðə wʌnz u hædn dʒɔɪn ə pæsɪŋ ɑɹmi - hædn sʌfɝd fɹəm ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl.

"Let me know when Tarn and Elyas get back," Perrin said to Gaul. Perrin had sent each one separately to visit nearby villages and make certain the people there - the ones who hadn't joined a passing army - hadn't suffered from the bubble of evil.

bɹəleɪn hæd kəmpoʊz hɝsɛlf, hɝ hæn bændədʒd. ʃi ɡeɪv ðə ɹipɔɹt tə hɪm hɝsɛlf, fɹəm əɹ tɛnt, seɪɪŋ haʊ mɛni ʌv əɹ soʊlʒɝz hæd bɪn wundəd, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə neɪmz ə ðə mɛn ðeɪd lɔst.

Berelain had composed herself, her hand bandaged. She gave the report to him herself, from her tent, saying how many of her soldiers had been wounded, giving the names of the men they'd lost.

oʊnli sɪks fɹəm əɹ kæmp.

Only six from her camp.

pɛɹɪn jɔn əz i lɛf ðə tɛnt, sɛndɪŋ ɝɑvin tə tʃɛk ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɡɔl hæd ɹʌn ɔf tə hɛlp wɪð kæɹiɪŋ səm ə ðə wundəd, ən pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf əloʊn əz i wɔk daʊn ðə pæθ təwɔɹɾ æliændɝz sɛkʃən ə kæmp.

Perrin yawned as he left the tent, sending Aravine to check on the Aes Sedai. Gaul had run off to help with carrying some of the wounded, and Perrin found himself alone as he walked down the path toward Alliandre's section of camp.

hɪz hæmɝ hædn tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm. soʊ fɑɹ əz i nu, ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli wɛpən ɑn ɛniwʌnz pɝsən ðət hædn ɹɪspɑndɪd tə ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl. wʌɾ ɪt min?

His hammer hadn't tried to kill him. So far as he knew, it was the only weapon on anyone's person that hadn't responded to the bubble of evil. What did it mean?

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, pɔzɪŋ ɪn θɔɾ əz i hɝd sʌmwʌn dʒɑɡɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə pæθ təwɔɹd hɪm. hi kɑt tɑɹnz sɛnt, ən tɝn tə mit ðə stɝɾi mæn əz i ɝaɪvd.

He shook his head, then hesitated, pausing in thought as he heard someone jogging along the path toward him. He caught Tarn's scent, and turned to meet the sturdy man as he arrived.

"pɛɹɪn, sʌn," tæm sɛd, aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ. "sʌmθɪŋ ənjuʒəwəl dʒʌs hæpənd."

"Perrin, son," Tam said, out of breath from running. "Something unusual just happened."

"ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl hɪt ðə vɪlədʒ?" pɛɹɪn æskt, əlɑɹmd. "wɝ pipəl hɝt?"

"The bubble of evil hit the village?" Perrin asked, alarmed. "Were people hurt?"

"oʊ, noʊ," tæm sɛd. "nɑt ðæt. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz faɪn. ðeɪ dɪdn ivən noʊɾəs ɛniθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ.

"Oh, no," Tam said. "Not that. The village was fine. They didn't even notice anything was wrong.

ðɪs ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls." tæm smɛld ɑd. θɔtfəl, wɝid.

This is something else." Tam smelled odd. Thoughtful, worried.

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. "wʌt? wʌts hæpənɪŋ?"

Perrin frowned. "What? What's happening?"

"aɪ . . . wɛl, aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ, sʌn," tæm sɛd. "liv ðə kæmp. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wən əl bi bæk."

"I . . . well, I have to go, son," Tam said. "Leave the camp. I don't know when I'll be back."

"ɪz ðɪs - "

"Is this - "

"ɪɾ əz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks," tæm sɛd. "aɪv bɪn toʊld aɪ kæn seɪ mʌtʃ. bʌɾ ɪts əbaʊt ɹænd."

"It has nothing to do with the Whitecloaks," Tam said. "I've been told I can't say much. But it's about Rand."

ðə kʌlɝz swɝld. ɹænd wɔk ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz dɑɹk.

The colors swirled. Rand walked the hallways of the Stone of Tear. His expression was dark.

deɪnʒɝəs.

Dangerous.

"pɛɹɪn," tæm sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ nid tə du. ɪɾ ɪnvɑlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən aɪ hæv tə liv jə naʊ. aɪ kæn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ðeɪ meɪd mi swɛɹ ɪt."

"Perrin," Tam said, "I think this is something I need to do. It involves Aes Sedai, and I have to leave you now. I can't say anything else. They made me swear it."

pɛɹɪn lʊkt ɪndə tɑɹnz aɪz ən sɔ ðə sənsɛɹəɾi ðɛɹ. hi nɑɾəd.

Perrin looked into Tarn's eyes and saw the sincerity there. He nodded.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn. jə niɾ ɛni hɛlp? sʌmwʌn tə ɡoʊ wɪð ju, wɛɹɛvɝ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ?"

"All right, then. You need any help? Someone to go with you, wherever you're going?"

"aɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt," tɑɹn sɛd. hi smɛld ɪmbɛɹəst. wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn? "aɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛt jə səm hɛlp, sʌn." hi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. "juv dʌn wɛl hɪɹ. aɪm pɹaʊɾ ə ju, ən jəɹ fɑðɝ wəd bi tu. kip ɪɾ ʌp. əl si jə ət ðə læs bæɾəl, ɪf nɑt bɪfɔɹ."

"I'll be all right," Tarn said. He smelled embarrassed. What was going on? "I'll try to get you some help, son." He laid a hand on Perrin's shoulder. "You've done well here. I'm proud of you, and your father would be too. Keep it up. I'll see you at the Last Battle, if not before."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. tɑɹn hɝiɾ ɔf təwɔɹɾ ɪz tɛnt, pɝhæps tə pæk.

Perrin nodded. Tarn hurried off toward his tent, perhaps to pack.

ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə lʊk ɹiɡəl waɪl biɪŋ kæɹiɾ ətɑp ðə keɪɛmlɪn sɪɾi wɔl ɑn ə lɪɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn dɪɾ əɹ bɛst. səmtaɪmz ɡɛɾɪŋ wʌt jə wɑntəd wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən lʊkɪŋ ɹiɡəl.

It was hard to look regal while being carried atop the Caemlyn city wall on a litter, but Elayne did her best. Sometimes getting what you wanted was more important than looking regal.

bɛd ɹɛst! fəɹ ə kwin! wɛl, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə kip mɛlfən fɹəm hʌvɝɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ, ʃid ɡɪvən ən oʊθ ðət ʃi wəd steɪ ɔf əɹ fit. bʌt ʃid sɛd nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt steɪɪŋ ɪn əɹ bɛdʒɹum.

Bed rest! For a queen! Well, in order to keep Melfane from hovering over her, she'd given an oath that she would stay off her feet. But she'd said nothing about staying in her bedroom.

fɔɹ ɡɑɹdzmɪn kæɹid ðə lɪɾɝ haɪ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ɪleɪn sæt seɪfli bɪtwin ɑɹmɹɛsts, wɛɹɪŋ ə kɹɪmzən ɡaʊn, hɛɹ kɛɹfəli bɹʌʃt, ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ ətɑp əɹ hɛd.

Four Guardsmen carried the litter high on their shoulders. Elayne sat safely between armrests, wearing a crimson gown, hair carefully brushed, the Rose Crown of Andor atop her head.

ðə deɪ wɑz mʌɡi, ðə wɛðɝ tɝnɪŋ wɔɹm, ðə skaɪ stɪl dɑɹk wɪð klaʊdz. ʃi spɛɹɾ ə moʊmən tə fil ɡɪlti fəɹ meɪkɪŋ ðə pʊɹ mɛn, ɪn dʒɹɛs junəfɔɹm, kæɹi hɝ θɹu ðɪs ɝli-sʌmɝ hit. bʌt ðiz mɛn wəd ɹaɪd tə bæɾəl ɪn əɹ neɪm; ðeɪ kəd stæn ə lɪɾəl wɔɹm wɛðɝ. haʊ ɔfən dɪd ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɡɛt ði ɑnɝ ə kæɹiɪŋ ðɛɹ kwin, ɛniweɪ?

The day was muggy, the weather turning warm, the sky still dark with clouds. She spared a moment to feel guilty for making the poor men, in dress uniform, carry her through this early-summer heat. But these men would ride to battle in her name; they could stand a little warm weather. How often did Guardsmen get the honor of carrying their queen, anyway?

bɝdʒɪt stʃɹoʊɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə bɛd, ən ðə bɑn ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət ʃi wɑz əmjuzd. ɪleɪn hæd fɪɹd ʃid tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ðɪs ɪkskɝʒən, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd ʃi hæd læft! bɝdʒɪt mʌst əv dɪtɝmən ðət ðɪs deɪz æktɪvəɾiz - ðoʊ baʊn tə əpsɛt mɛlfən - wɝ noʊ ɹil ɹɪsk tə ɪleɪn əɹ əɹ beɪbz. tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ, ðət mɛn ðɪs wɑz ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə si ɪleɪn ɡɛt pɝeɪɾɪd θɹu taʊn lʊkɪŋ fulɪʃ.

Birgitte strode alongside the bed, and the bond indicated that she was amused. Elayne had feared she'd try to stop this excursion, but instead she had laughed! Birgitte must have determined that this day's activities - though bound to upset Melfane - were no real risk to Elayne or her babes. To the Warder, that meant this was an opportunity to see Elayne get paraded through town looking foolish.

ɪleɪn wɪnst. wʌt wəd ðə pipəl seɪ? ðə kwin, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə lɪɾɝ, biɪŋ mɑɹtʃt tə ði aʊɾɝ wɔl? wɛl, ɪleɪn wɑzn əbaʊt tə lɛt ɹumɝz kip əɹ fɹəm siɪŋ ðə tɛs fɝsthænd, ən ʃi wɑzn əbaʊt tə bi bʊlid baɪ ə tɝænɪkəl mɪdwaɪf.

Elayne winced. What would the people say? The Queen, riding a litter, being marched to the outer wall? Well, Elayne wasn't about to let rumors keep her from seeing the test firsthand, and she wasn't about to be bullied by a tyrannical midwife.

ʃi hæd kwaɪɾ ə vju fɹəm ðə wɔl. ðə filz liɾɪŋ tə ɑɹɪŋɡəl leɪ oʊpən tə hɝ lɛft; ðə sɪɾi bʌsəl tə hɝ ɹaɪt. ðoʊz filz wɝ tu bɹaʊn. ɹɪpɔɹts fɹəm ɝaʊn ðə ɹɛlm wɝ daɪɹ. naɪn filz ɪn tɛn hæd feɪld.

She had quite a view from the wall. The fields leading to Aringill lay open to her left; the city bustled to her right. Those fields were too brown. Reports from around the realm were dire. Nine fields in ten had failed.

ɪleɪnz pɔɹɾɝz kæɹiɾ əɹ ʌp tə wʌn ə ðə wɔlz taʊɝ tɝəts, ðən hɪɾ ə snæɡ əz ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðə poʊlz ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ wɝ tu lɔŋ tə meɪk ðə tɝnz ɑn ðə stɛɹz ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊɝ; ðə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən wɑz səpoʊz tə hæpən ətɑp ɪt. lʌkəli, ðəɹ wɝ ɔltɝnəɾɪv ʃɔɹt hændhoʊlz fəɹ dʒʌst sətʃ sɪtʃueɪʃənz. ðeɪ ɹimuv ðə poʊlz, swɪtʃt tə ðə hændhoʊlz, ən pɹoʊ-tʃiɾəd.

Elayne's porters carried her up to one of the wall's tower turrets, then hit a snag as they realized the poles on the litter were too long to make the turns on the stairs inside the tower; the demonstration was supposed to happen atop it. Luckily, there were alternative short handholds for just such situations. They removed the poles, switched to the handholds, and pro-ceeded.

waɪl ðeɪ kæɹiɾ əɹ ʌp, ʃi dɪstʃɹæktəd hɝsɛlf baɪ θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt kɛɹhin. ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz ðəɹ ɔl kleɪm tə bi iɡɝli əweɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɑɹ-ɹaɪvəl tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn, ən jɛt nʌn ɔfɝd mɔɹ ðən ðə moʊs flæksɪd səpɔɹt. deɪz deɪmɑɹ wɑz fʊli ɪn ɪfɛkt, ən ðə pɑstʃɝɪŋ fəɹ ɪleɪnz əsɛnt - əɹ əɹ feɪljɝ tə əsɛnd - hæd bɪɡʌn ðə moʊmən ɹænd hæd mɛnʃən ðəɾ i ɪntɛndəd ðə neɪʃən tə bi hɝz.

While they carried her up, she distracted herself by thinking about Cairhien. The noble Houses there all claimed to be eagerly awaiting her ar-rival to take the throne, and yet none offered more than the most flaccid support. Daes Dae'mar was fully in effect, and the posturing for Elayne's ascent - or her failure to ascend - had begun the moment Rand had mentioned that he intended the nation to be hers.

ɪn kɛɹhin, ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən pəlɪɾəkəl wɪnz ɔlweɪz blu ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃənz.

In Cairhien, a hundred different political winds always blew in a hundred different directions.

ʃi dɪdn əv taɪm tə lɝn ɔl ə ðə dɪfɹən fækʃənz bɪfɔɹ ʃi tʊk ðə θɹoʊn. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf ʃi wɑz sin əz pleɪɪŋ ðə ɡeɪm, ʃi kəd bi sin əz sʌmwʌn tə dɪfit. ʃi hæd tə faɪn ə weɪ tə siz ðə sʌn θɹoʊn wɪθaʊt mɪksɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ɪn ðə loʊkəl haʊs pɑlətɪks.

She didn't have time to learn all of the different factions before she took the throne. Besides, if she was seen as playing the game, she could be seen as someone to defeat. She had to find a way to seize the Sun Throne without mixing too much in the local House politics.

ɪleɪnz lɪɾɝ kɹikt ʌp ən kɹɛstəd ðə lɪp ə ðə taʊɝz tɝət. ətɑp ðə taʊɝ, ɑlʌdʒɹə stʊd wɪð wʌn ə hɝ pɹoʊɾətaɪp dʒɹæɡənz. ðə bɹɑnz tub wɑz kwaɪt lɔŋ ən sɛɾ ɪn ə fɹeɪmwɝk ʌv wʊd. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə dʌmi, fəɹ dɪspleɪ. ə sɛkənd, wɝkɪŋ dʒɹæɡən hæd bɪn sɛɾ ʌp ətɑp ðə nɛks taʊɝ daʊn ðə wɔl. ɪt wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ ðəɾ ɪleɪn wʊdn bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ ɪf sʌmθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ.

Elayne's litter creaked up and crested the lip of the tower's turret. Atop the tower, Aludra stood with one of her prototype dragons. The bronze tube was quite long and set in a framework of wood. It was just a dummy, for display. A second, working dragon had been set up atop the next tower down the wall. It was far enough away that Elayne wouldn't be in danger if something went wrong.

ðə slɛndɝ tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən sim tə teɪk noʊ θɔt fəɹ ðə fæk ðət ʃi wɑz dɪlɪvɝɪŋ ə pətɛnʃəli wɝld-tʃeɪnʒɪŋ wɛpən tə ðə kwin ʌv ə fɔɹən kʌntʃɹi; ɔl ɑlʌdʒɹə sim tə wɑnt wɑz ə weɪ tə ɡɛt bæk ət ðə sintʃæn, əɹ soʊ mæt hæɾ ɪkspleɪnd. ɪleɪn hæd spɛn səm taɪm wɪð ðə wʊmən waɪl tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð lukəz mənædʒɝi, bʌt stɪl wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ tʃɹʌstwɝði ʃi wɑz. ʃiɾ əv mæstɝ nɔɹi kip ən aɪ ɑn hɝ.

The slender Taraboner woman seemed to take no thought for the fact that she was delivering a potentially world-changing weapon to the queen of a foreign country; all Aludra seemed to want was a way to get back at the Seanchan, or so Mat had explained. Elayne had spent some time with the woman while traveling with Luca's menagerie, but still wasn't certain how trustworthy she was. She'd have Master Norry keep an eye on her.

əsumɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ðə dʒɹæɡənz wɝkt. ɪleɪn spɛɹɾ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns fəɹ ðə pipəl daʊn bɪloʊ. oʊnli ðən dɪd ʃi ɹilaɪz haʊ haɪ ʌp ʃi ɹɪli wɑz. laɪt!

Assuming, of course, the dragons worked. Elayne spared another glance for the people down below. Only then did she realize how high up she really was. Light!

aɪm seɪf, ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf. mɪnz vjuɪŋ. nɑt ðət ʃi sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðət tə bɝdʒɪt, nɑɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ən ʃi dɪɾ ɪntɛn tə stɑp teɪkɪŋ soʊ mɛni ɹɪsks. ðɪs wɑzn ə ɹɪsk. nɑt ɹɪli.

I'm safe, she reminded herself. Min's viewing. Not that she said anything like that to Birgitte, not any longer. And she did intend to stop taking so many risks. This wasn't a risk. Not really.

ʃi tɝn əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɡɹu dɪzi ən ɪnspɛktɪd ðə dʒɹæɡən mɔɹ kloʊsli. ɪt wɑz ʃeɪp laɪk ə lɑɹdʒ bɹɑnz bɛl, ðoʊ lɔŋɡɝ ən nɛɹoʊɝ. laɪk ən ɪnɔɹməs veɪs tɝn ɑn ɪts saɪd. ɪleɪn hæd ɹəsiv mɔɹ ðən wʌn mɪsɪv fɹəm ðə sɪɾiz aɪɹeɪt bɛlfndɝz. ɑlʌdʒɹə ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ əɹ ɔɹɾɝz bi kæɹiɾ aʊɾ ɪɡzækli ən hæd fɔɹs ðə mɛn tə ɹikæs ðə tub θɹi taɪmz.

She turned away before she grew dizzy and inspected the dragon more closely. It was shaped like a large bronze bell, though longer and narrower. Like an enormous vase turned on its side. Elayne had received more than one missive from the city's irate bellfounders. Aludra insisted that her orders be carried out exactly and had forced the men to recast the tube three times.

leɪt ðə pɹiviəs naɪt, ə laʊd kɹæk hæd saʊndəɾ əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾi. əz ɛn stoʊn wɔl hæd fɔlən sʌmwɛɹ əɹ ə boʊlt ə laɪtnɪŋ hæd stʃɹʌk. ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ɪleɪn hæd ɹəsivd ə noʊt fɹəm ɑlʌdʒɹə.

Late the previous night, a loud crack had sounded across the city. As n stone wall had fallen somewhere or a bolt of lightning had struck. This morning Elayne had received a note from Aludra.

fɝs tɛst ə səksɛs, ɪt hæd ɹɛd. mit mi tədeɪ ɑn sɪɾi wɔl fəɹ dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən.

First test a success, it had read. Meet me today on city wall for demonstration.

"jɔɹ mædʒəsti," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd. "ju ɑɹ . . . wɛl, jɛs?"

"Your Majesty," Aludra said. "You are . . . well, yes?"

"aɪ wɪl bi faɪn, ɑlʌdʒɹə," ɪleɪn sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪnteɪn əɹ dɪɡnəɾi. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹɛɾi?"

"I will be fine, Aludra," Elayne said, trying to maintain her dignity. "The dragon is ready?"

"ɪɾ ɪz," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd. ʃi wɔɹ ə lɔŋ bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs, hɝ blæk weɪvi hɛɹ lus, kʌmɪŋ daʊn tə hɝ weɪst. waɪ noʊ bɹeɪdz tədeɪ? ɑlʌdʒɹə dɪdn sim tə kɛɹ fəɹ dʒuəlɹi, ən ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ wɛɹ ɛni. ə ɡɹup ə faɪv mɛn fɹəm mæts bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hæn stʊd wɪð hɝ, wʌn kæɹiɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə tʃɪmni bɹʌʃ ə səm sɔɹt. ənʌðɝ hæɾ ə mɛɾəl sfɪɹ ɪn ɪz hænz, ən ənʌðɝ kæɹiɾ ə smɔl wʊɾən kæsk.

"It is," Aludra said. She wore a long brown dress, her black wavy hair loose, coming down to her waist. Why no braids today? Aludra didn't seem to care for jewelry, and Elayne had never seen her wear any. A group of five men from Mat's Band of the Red Hand stood with her, one carrying what appeared to be a chimney brush of some sort. Another had a metal sphere in his hands, and another carried a small wooden cask.

ɪleɪn kəd si ə sɪməlɝ ɡɹup ɑn ðə nɛks taʊɝ oʊvɝ. sʌmwʌn ðəɹ ɹeɪzd ə hæɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən weɪvd ət hɝ. mæt wɑntəd tə wɑtʃ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ wɪð ðə wɝkɪŋ dʒɹæɡən, ɪt simd.

Elayne could see a similar group on the next tower over. Someone there raised a hat into the air and waved at her. Mat wanted to watch from the tower with the working dragon, it seemed.

fulhɑɹɾi mæn. wʌɾ ɪf ðə θɪŋ ɪksploʊɾəd laɪk ə naɪtfloʊɝ?

Foolhardy man. What if the thing exploded like a nightflower?

"ðə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən, ðɛn," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd, "wi ʃæl bɪɡɪn. ðiz mɛn hɪɹ wɪl ʃoʊ jə wʌɾ ɪz biɪŋ dʌn ɑn ði ʌðɝ taʊɝ." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪleɪn. "hɝ mædʒəsti, aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd pɹɑp əɹ ʌp, soʊ ðət ʃi kən si ðə dɪspleɪ."

"The demonstration, then," Aludra said, "we shall begin. These men here will show you what is being done on the other tower." She hesitated as she regarded Elayne. "Her Majesty, I think we should prop her up, so that she can see the display."

ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, ðeɪd loʊkeɪɾəd səm smɔl bɑksəz tə pleɪs bɪniθ ðə lɪɾɝ ən ɛləveɪɾ ɪleɪn soʊ ðət ʃi kəd si oʊvɝ ðə taʊɝz kɹɛnələ-ʃənz. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət sʌmθɪŋ hæd bɪn kənstʃɹʌktəɾ ɑn ə dɪstən hɪlsaɪd, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz tu fɑɹ fəɹ ɪleɪn tə meɪk aʊt. ɑlʌdʒɹə pʊld aʊt sɛvɹəl lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz ən hændəd wʌn itʃ tə ɪleɪn ən bɝdʒɪt.

A few minutes later, they'd located some small boxes to place beneath the litter and elevate Elayne so that she could see over the tower's crenela-tions. It appeared that something had been constructed on a distant hillside, though it was too far for Elayne to make out. Aludra pulled out several looking glasses and handed one each to Elayne and Birgitte.

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ ɡlæs tə hɝ aɪ. dʒɹɛsɪŋ dʌmiz. ɑlʌdʒɹə hæd sɛɾ ʌp səm fɪfti ʌv əm ɪn ɹæŋks ɑn ðə fɑɹ hɪl. laɪt! wɛɹ hæd ʃi ɡɑɾən soʊ mɛni? laɪkli, ɪleɪn wəd bi ɡɛɾɪŋ səm wɝɾi mɪsɪvz fɹəm ɡaʊnmeɪkɝz əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾi.

Elayne raised her glass to her eye. Dressing dummies. Aludra had set up some fifty of them in ranks on the far hill. Light! Where had she gotten so many? Likely, Elayne would be getting some wordy missives from gownmakers across the city.

mæt hæd pɹɑməs ðɪs wəd bi wɝθ pɹæktəkli ɛni kɑst. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət wɑz mæt. hi wɑzn ɪɡzækli ðə moʊst ɹɪlaɪəbəl pɝsən ɝaʊnd.

Mat had promised this would be worth practically any cost. Of course, that was Mat. He wasn't exactly the most reliable person around.

hi 'ɛs nɑt ðə wʌn u lɔst ən ɪnvæljəbəl tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə ðə ʃædoʊ, ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf. ʃi ɡɹɪməst. ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ, ʃi kæɹiɾ ənʌðɝ ɹɛplɪkə ʌv ðə fɑkshɛd. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə θɹi ʃid kɹieɪɾəd soʊ fɑɹ. ɪf ʃi wɑz gɑnə bi kənfaɪn tə hɝ bɛd, ðən ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl meɪk jus ə hɝ taɪm. ɪt wəd bi ə lɑt lɛs fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪf ʃi kəd tʃænəl kənsɪstənli.

He 's not the one who lost an invaluable ter'angreal to the Shadow, she reminded herself. She grimaced. In her pouch, she carried another replica of the foxhead. It was one of three she'd created so far. If she was going to be confined to her bed, then she might as well make use of her time. It would be a lot less frustrating if she could channel consistently.

ɔl θɹi ʌv ðə ɹɛplɪkə fɑkshɛd mədæljənz wɝkt əz ðə fɝst ɹɛplɪkə hæd. ʃi kʊdn tʃænəl waɪl wɛɹɪŋ wʌn, ən ə paʊɝfəl wiv kəɾ oʊvɝwɛlm ðɛm. ʃi ɹɪli niɾəd ðəɾ ɝɪdʒənəl bæk fəɹ fɝðɝ stʌɾi.

All three of the replica foxhead medallions worked as the first replica had. She couldn't channel while wearing one, and a powerful weave could overwhelm them. She really needed that original back for further study.

"ju kən si, jəɹ mædʒəsti," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛɾ ɪn ə stɪf vɔɪs, əz ɪf ʌnəkəs-toʊm tə ɡɪvɪŋ ə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən, "ðæt wiv tʃɹaɪd tə ɹeɪ-kɹieɪt ðə kəndɪʃənz ʌndɝ wɪtʃ jə maɪt meɪk jus ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz, jɛs?"

"You can see, Your Majesty," Aludra said in a stiff voice, as if unaccus-tomed to giving a demonstration, "that we've tried to re-create the conditions under which you might make use of the dragons, yes?"

ɪksɛpt ɪnstɛɾ ə fɪfti dʒɹɛsɪŋ dʌmiz, wɪl əv ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks, ɪleɪn θɔt.

Except instead of fifty dressing dummies, we'll have a hundred thousand Trollocs, Elayne thought.

"ðə nɛks taʊɝ, jə ʃəd lʊk əɾ ɪt," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ.

"The next tower, you should look at it," Aludra said, gesturing.

ɪleɪn tɝn ðə ɡlæs tə lʊk ət ðə nɛks taʊɝ daʊn ðə wɔl. ʃi kəd si faɪv mɛmbɝz ə ðə bæn ðɛɹ, dʒɹɛst ɪn junəfɔɹmz, weɪɾɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ dʒɹæɡən. mæt wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə θɪŋ, ɹaɪt daʊn ðə tub "ðiz əv tʃɹeɪn sʌmwʌɾ ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡənz," ɑlʌdʒɹə kəntɪnjud "bʌt ðeɪ də nɑɾ əv ði ɪfɪʃənsi aɪ wəd laɪk. ðəl də fəɹ naʊ jɛs?"

Elayne turned the glass to look at the next tower down the wall. She could see five members of the Band there, dressed in uniforms, waiting with another dragon. Mat was looking in the thing, right down the tube "These have trained somewhat on the dragons," Aludra continued "But they do not have the efficiency I would like. They will do for now yes?"

ɪleɪn loʊɝɾ əɹ ɡlæs əz ðə mɛn pʊl ðə dʌmi tub bæk__ɪt wɑz ɑn ə sɛɾ ʌv wilz - ən ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ɪɾ ʌp ə bɪt təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ. wʌn pɔɹd səm blæk paʊɾɝ ɪn fɹəm ɪz kæsk, ðən ənʌðɝ stʌft ɪn ə wɑɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ ðə mæn wɪð ðə lɔŋ poʊl ɹæmɪŋ ɪt daʊn ðə tub. ðət wɑzn ə tʃɪmni bɹʌʃ i hɛld, bʌt səm kaɪndə tul juz fəɹ pækɪŋ.

Elayne lowered her glass as the men pulled the dummy tube back__it was on a set of wheels - and rotated it up a bit toward the sky. One poured some black powder in from his cask, then another stuffed in a wad of something. This was followed by the man with the long pole ramming it down the tube. That wasn't a chimney brush he held, but some kind of tool used for packing.

"ðæt lʊks laɪk ðə paʊɾɝ ɪnsaɪɾ ə naɪtfloʊɝ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. ʃi fɛlt wɛɹi.

"That looks like the powder inside a nightflower," Birgitte said. She felt wary.

ɑlʌdʒɹə ʃɑt ðə wɔɹɾɝ ə ɡlæns. "æn haʊ dʒju noʊ wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪɾ ə naɪtfloʊɝ, mɛɹiən?

Aludra shot the Warder a glance. "And how do you know what is inside a nightflower, Maerion?

jə də ɹilaɪz haʊ deɪnʒɝəs ɪts tə oʊpən wʌn ə ðoʊz, jɛs?"

You do realize how dangerous it is to open one of those, yes?"

bɝdʒɪt ʃɹʌɡd.

Birgitte shrugged.

ɑlʌdʒɹə fɹaʊnd, bʌt ɡɑt noʊ ɹɪspɑns, soʊ tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən kɑm hɝsɛlf. "ðə dɪvaɪs, ɪts pɝfəkli seɪf. wi sɛɾ ʌp ði ʌðɝ dʒɹæɡən tə də ðə faɪɹɪŋ, soʊ ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ deɪnʒɝ, jɛs? bʌt ðəɹ wəd nɑt bi deɪnʒɝ ɛniweɪ. ðə kæstɪŋ ɪz ɡʊɾ ən maɪ kælkjəleɪʃənz, ðeɪ ɑɹ pɝfəkt."

Aludra frowned, but got no response, so took a deep breath and calmed herself. "The device, it is perfectly safe. We set up the other dragon to do the firing, so there would be no danger, yes? But there would not be danger anyway. The casting is good and my calculations, they are perfect."

"ɪleɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, "aɪ stɪl θɪŋk wid bi bɛɾɝ ɔf wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə wɔl daʊn bɪloʊ. ivən ɪf ðɪs wʌn bɪsaɪɾ əs ɪzən gɑnə bi lɪt."

"Elayne," Birgitte said, "I still think we'd be better off watching from the wall down below. Even if this one beside us isn't going to be lit."

"æftɝ ɔl aɪ wɛn θɹu tə ɡɛɾ ʌp hɪɹ?" ɪleɪn æskt. "noʊ θæŋk ju. ɑlʌdʒɹə, jə meɪ pɹəsid."

"After all I went through to get up here?" Elayne asked. "No thank you. Aludra, you may proceed."

ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd bɝdʒɪts ənɔɪəns. dɪɾ ɑlʌdʒɹə ɹɪli θɪŋk ʃi kəd hɪt wʌn ə ðoʊz dʒɹɛsɪŋ dʌmiz wɪð əɹ aɪɝn sfɪɹ? ðət wɑz ə lɔŋ weɪ tə ɡoʊ, ən ðə sfɪɹ wɑz soʊ smɔl, bɛɹli waɪɾɝ ðən ə mænz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt pɑm. hæɾ ɪleɪn ɪnvɛstəɾ ɔl ə ðɪs ɛfɝt tə ɡɛt sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd wɝk mɔɹ pʊɹli ðən ə kæɾəpʌlt? ðɪs dʒɹæɡən saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ɪt kəd θɹoʊ ɪts sfɪɹ fɑɹðɝ, bʌt ðə boʊldɝz tɔs baɪ ə kæɾəpʌlt wɝ mɛni taɪmz lɑɹdʒɝ.

She ignored Birgitte's annoyance. Did Aludra really think she could hit one of those dressing dummies with her iron sphere? That was a long way to go, and the sphere was so small, barely wider than a man's outstretched palm. Had Elayne invested all of this effort to get something that would work more poorly than a catapult? This dragon sounded as if it could throw its sphere farther, but the boulders tossed by a catapult were many times larger.

ðə mɛn fɪnɪʃt. ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ mæn tʌtʃt ə smɔl tɔɹtʃ tə ə fjuz stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sfɪɹ ən ɹoʊld ɪɾ ɪndə ðə tub; ðən ðeɪ tɝn ðə tub tə feɪs dɝɛkli aʊtwɝd.

The men finished. The remaining man touched a small torch to a fuse sticking out of the sphere and rolled it into the tube; then they turned the tube to face directly outward.

"ju si?" ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd, pæɾɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən. "θɹi mɛn ɪz bɛst. fɔɹ fəɹ seɪfti, ɪn keɪs wʌn fɔlz.

"You see?" Aludra said, patting the dragon. "Three men is best. Four for safety, in case one falls.

wʌn kəd də ðə wɝk ɪf i hæd tə, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi sloʊ."

One could do the work if he had to, but it would be slow."

ðə mɛn stɛp bæk əz ɑlʌdʒɹə ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɛd flæɡ. ʃi hɛld ɪɾ ʌp ɪn ði ɛɹ, sɪɡnəlɪŋ ði ʌðɝ tim ɑn ðə nɛks taʊɝ daʊn ðə wɔl. ɪleɪn foʊkəst ɑn əm wɪð ðə ɡlæs. wʌn kæɹiɾ ə smɔl tɔɹtʃ. mæt wɑtʃt wɪð ə kjʊɹiəs ɪkspɹɛʃən.

The men stepped back as Aludra got out a red flag. She held it up in the air, signaling the other team on the next tower down the wall. Elayne focused on them with the glass. One carried a small torch. Mat watched with a curious expression.

ɑlʌdʒɹə loʊɝɾ əɹ flæɡ. ðə soʊlʒɝ tʌtʃt ɪz bɝnɪŋ tɔɹtʃ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən.

Aludra lowered her flag. The soldier touched his burning torch to the side of the dragon.

ði ɪksploʊsɪv saʊn ðət fɑloʊd wɑz soʊ paʊɝfəl ðəɾ ɪt meɪɾ ɪleɪn dʒʌmp- ðə bum wɑz əz ʃɑɹp əz ə θʌndɝklæp, ən ʃi hɝɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns wʌt saʊndəd laɪk ən ɛkoʊ ʌv ði ɪksploʊʒən. ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ bɹɛst, ən ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ.

The explosive sound that followed was so powerful that it made Elayne jump- The boom was as sharp as a thunderclap, and she heard in the distance what sounded like an echo of the explosion. She raised a hand to her breast, and remembered to draw breath.

ə pɑkəɾ ɑn ðə maʊntənsaɪɾ ɪksploʊɾəd ɪn ə mæsɪv spɹeɪ ʌv dʌst ən ɝθ. ðə ɡɹaʊn sim tə tʃɹɛmbəl! ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd tɔɹn ʌp ði ɝθ wɪð ə wiv, bʌt ðə wʌn paʊɝ hædn bɪn juzd əɾ ɔl.

A pocket on the mountainside exploded in a massive spray of dust and earth. The ground seemed to tremble! It was as if an Aes Sedai had torn up the earth with a weave, but the One Power hadn't been used at all.

ɑlʌdʒɹə sim dɪsəpɔɪntɪd. ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hɝ aɪ. ðə blæs hæd mɪs ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ dʌmiz baɪ ə ɡʊd twɛnti peɪsɪz, bʌt hæd ɹɪpt ə hoʊl ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn faɪv peɪsɪz waɪd. dɪd ðə bɔl ɪksploʊd laɪk ə naɪtfloʊɝ tə kɑz ðæt? ðɪs dɪvaɪs wɑzn mɪɹli ən ɪmpɹuv kæɾəpʌlt əɹ tʃɹibətʃɛt; ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. sʌmθɪŋ keɪpəbəl ə smæʃɪŋ ən aɪɝn sfɪɹ ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð sətʃ fɔɹs ðəɾ ɪt blu oʊpən ə hoʊl, ðən pɝhæps ɪksploʊɾəd ɑn ɪts oʊn.

Aludra seemed disappointed. Elayne raised her looking glass to her eye. The blast had missed the dressing dummies by a good twenty paces, but had ripped a hole in the ground five paces wide. Did the ball explode like a nightflower to cause that? This device wasn't merely an improved catapult or trebuchet; it was something else. Something capable of smashing an iron sphere into the ground with such force that it blew open a hole, then perhaps exploded on its own.

waɪ, ʃi kəd laɪn ən ɪntaɪɝ wɔl wɪð ðiz dʒɹæɡənz! wɪð ɔl ə ðɛm faɪɹɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. . . .

Why, she could line an entire wall with these dragons! With all of them firing together. . . .

ɑlʌdʒɹə ɹeɪzd əɹ flæɡ əɡɛn; ɪleɪn wɑtʃt wɪð əɹ ɡlæs əz ðə mɛn ɑn ðə nɛks taʊɝ oʊvɝ klind, ðən ɹiloʊɾɪd, ðə tub. mæt wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɪz ɪɹz ən skaʊlɪŋ, wɪtʃ ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə smaɪl.

Aludra raised her flag again; Elayne watched with her glass as the men on the next tower over cleaned, then reloaded, the tube. Mat was holding his ears and scowling, which gave Elayne a smile.

hi ɹɪli ʃʊɾə wɑtʃt fɹəm əɹ taʊɝ. ðə ɹiloʊɾɪŋ pɹɑsɛs tʊk ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt taɪm, pɝhæps θɹi mɪnəts. ən ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə si ɪt hæpən mɔɹ kwɪkli?

He really should have watched from her tower. The reloading process took a very short time, perhaps three minutes. And Aludra said she intended to see it happen more quickly?

ɑlʌdʒɹə ɹoʊɾ ə sɛɾ ʌv ɔɹɾɝz ən sɛn ɪt baɪ mɛsənʒɝ tə ðə mɛn. ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒd ðə dʒɹæɡənz pəzɪʃən slaɪtli. ʃi weɪvd əɹ flæɡ; ɪleɪn stil hɝsɛlf fəɹ ənʌðɝ ɪksploʊʒən, bʌt stɪl dʒʌmpt wən ɪt keɪm.

Aludra wrote a set of orders and sent it by messenger to the men. They changed the dragon's position slightly. She waved her flag; Elayne steeled herself for another explosion, but still jumped when it came.

ðɪs taɪm, ðə blæst wɑz dɛd-ɑn, hɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹæŋk ə dʒɹɛsɪŋ dʌmiz. ðɛɹ tæɾɝd ɹɛmnəns spʌn θɹu ði ɛɹ. ðə bloʊ dɪstʃɹɔɪd faɪv əɹ sɪks, ən nɑk daʊn ə ɡʊd dʌzən ə ðɛm.

This time, the blast was dead-on, hitting in the very center of the rank of dressing dummies. Their tattered remnants spun through the air. The blow destroyed five or six, and knocked down a good dozen of them.

wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə faɪɝ ɛvɹi tu mɪnəts, hɪt soʊ fɑɹ əweɪ, ən dil sətʃ dɪstʃɹʌkʃən, ðiz wɛpənz wəd bi dɛdli. əz dɛdli əz dɑmɑm, pɝhæps. bɝdʒɪt wɑz stɪl lʊkɪŋ θɹu hɝ lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, ən waɪl əɹ feɪs wɑz ɪmpæsɪv, ɪleɪn kəd fil ðə wʊmənz əmeɪzmənt.

With the ability to fire every two minutes, hit so far away, and deal such destruction, these weapons would be deadly. As deadly as damame, perhaps. Birgitte was still looking through her looking glass, and while her face was impassive, Elayne could feel the woman's amazement.

"ðə wɛpən, jə faɪn ɪt plizɪŋ?" ɑlʌdʒɹə æskt.

"The weapon, you find it pleasing?" Aludra asked.

"aɪ faɪn ɪt plizɪŋ, ɑlʌdʒɹə," ɪleɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ faɪn ɪt plizɪŋ ɪndid. ðə ɹisɔɹsɪz ə ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi ɑɹ jʊɹz, ðə ɹisɔɹsɪz ʌv ɔl æn-dɔɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ sɛvɹəl mɔɹ bɛlfndɝz ɪn ændɝ." ʃi ɡlænst ət ði ɪluməneɪɾɝ. "bʌt jə mʌs kip ðə plænz ən dɪzaɪnz ə sikɹət. əl sɛnd ɡɑɹdz wɪð ju. wi kæn əfɔɹd tə lɛɾ ɛni ʌv ðə bɛlfbʌndɝz kənsɪɾɝ ðə vælju ʌv livɪŋ hoʊm ən sɛlɪŋ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən tə əɹ ɛnəmiz."

"I find it pleasing, Aludra," Elayne said, smiling. "I find it pleasing indeed. The resources of the entire city are yours, the resources of all An-dor. There are several more bellfounders in Andor." She glanced at the Illuminator. "But you must keep the plans and designs a secret. I will send Guards with you. We can't afford to let any of the bellfbunders consider the value of leaving home and selling information to our enemies."

"soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ doʊn ɹitʃ ðə sintʃæn," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd, "aɪ kɛɹ nɑt."

"So long as they don't reach the Seanchan," Aludra said, "I care not."

"wɛl, aɪ du," ɪleɪn sɛd. "æn ɪm ðə wʌn u wɪl si ðiz θɪŋz juz pɹɑpɝli. əl niɾ ən oʊθ aʊɾ ə ju, ɑlʌdʒɹə."

"Well, I do," Elayne said. "And I'm the one who will see these things used properly. I'll need an oath out of you, Aludra."

ðə wʊmən saɪd, bʌt ɡeɪv ɪt. ɪleɪn hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə tɝnɪŋ əm əɡɛnst ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən tʃɹɑləks ən sintʃæn. bʌt ʃi wəd fil mʌtʃ mɔɹ sɪkjʊɹ əbaʊɾ əɹ neɪʃən noʊɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd ðiz əɾ əɹ dɪspoʊzəl.

The woman sighed, but gave it. Elayne had no intention of turning them against anyone other than Trollocs and Seanchan. But she would feel much more secure about her nation knowing that she had these at her disposal.

ʃi smaɪld əz ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ɪt, ən faʊn ɪt dɪfəkəl tə kənteɪn əɹ ɪksaɪtmənt. bɝdʒɪt faɪnəli loʊɝɾ əɹ ɡlæs. ʃi fɛlt. . . sɑləm.

She smiled as she considered it, and found it difficult to contain her excitement. Birgitte finally lowered her glass. She felt. . . solemn.

"wʌt?" ɪleɪn æskt əz ðə ɡɑɹdz tʊk tɝnz wɪð əɹ ɡlæs, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə dɛvəsteɪʃən. ʃi fɛl səm ɑɾ ɪndaɪdʒɛstʃən. hæd ʃi iɾən sʌmθɪŋ bæd fəɹ lʌntʃ?

"What?" Elayne asked as the Guards took turns with her glass, inspecting the devastation. She felt some odd indigestion. Had she eaten something bad for lunch?

"ðə wɝl dʒʌs tʃeɪnʒd, ɪleɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, lɔŋ bɹeɪd swɪŋɪŋ slaɪtli. "ɪt dʒʌs tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ weɪ. aɪ hæv ə tɛɹəbəl filɪŋ ðəɾ ɪts oʊnli ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ."

"The world just changed, Elayne," Birgitte said, shaking her head, long braid swinging slightly. "It just changed in a very large way. I have a terrible feeling that it's only the beginning."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi


CHAPTER 30

mɛn dʒɹim hɪɹ


Men Dream Here

ðiz waɪtkloʊks ɑɹ ə taɪt-lɪpt ɡɹup, maɪ leɪɾi," lətʃəl sɛd wɪð ə smʌɡ smaɪl, "bʌt ðəɹ stɪl mɛn. mɛn u hævən sin ə wʊmən ɪn ə waɪl, aɪ θɪŋk. ðəɾ ɔlweɪz meɪks əm luz wʌt fju bɹeɪnz ðeɪ hæv."

These Whitecloaks are a tight-lipped group, my Lady," Lacile said with a smug smile, "but they're still men. Men who haven't seen a woman in a while, I think. That always makes them lose what few brains they have."

feɪl wɔk ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, ðə skaɪ dɑɹk, læntɝn hɛl bɪfɔɹ hɝ. pɛɹɪn wɑz əslip; hid ɹɪtaɪɹɾ ɝli ðiz læs fju deɪz, sikɪŋ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd ɹɪlʌktənli əɡɹid tə dɪleɪ ðə tʃɹaɪəl, bʌt pɛɹɪn stɪl ʃʊɾə bɪn pɹipɛɹɪŋ ɪz wɝdz tə spik ðɛɹ. hi ɡɹʌmbəl ðəɾ i ɔlɹɛɾi nu wʌɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ. noʊɪŋ hɪm, hid dʒʌs tɛl mɔɹ-ɡeɪz wʌt hæd hæpənd, stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ əz juʒəwəl.

Faile walked the horselines, the sky dark, lantern held before her. Perrin was asleep; he'd retired early these last few days, seeking the wolf dream. The Whitecloaks had reluctantly agreed to delay the trial, but Perrin still should have been preparing his words to speak there. He grumbled that he already knew what he was going to say. Knowing him, he'd just tell Mor-gase what had happened, straightforward as usual.

lətʃəl ən sɛlənd wɔkt ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə feɪl. ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə tʃɑ feɪl wɔk bɪhaɪnd, kipɪŋ kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ fəɹ ɛniwʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə bi wɪðɪn ɪɹʃɑt.

Lacile and Selande walked on either side of Faile. Other members of Cha Faile walked behind, keeping careful watch for anyone close enough to be within earshot.

"aɪ θɪŋk ðə waɪtkloʊks nu wi wɝ ðəɹ tə spaɪ," sɛlən sɛd. ðə ʃɔɹt, peɪl wʊmən wɔkt wɪð hæn ɑn əɹ sɔɹd. ðə stæns dɪdn sim əz ɑkwɝɾ əz ɪt wʌns hæd; sɛlən hæd teɪkən əɹ sɔɹd tʃɹeɪnɪŋ sɪɹiəsli.

"I think the Whitecloaks knew we were there to spy," Selande said. The short, pale woman walked with hand on her sword. The stance didn't seem as awkward as it once had; Selande had taken her sword training seriously.

"noʊ, aɪ daʊt ðeɪ ɡɛst," lətʃəl ɹɪplaɪd. ʃi stɪl wɔɹ ə sɪmpəl tæn blaʊs ən dɑɹkɝ bɹaʊn skɝt. sɛlən hæd tʃeɪnʒd bæk tə bɹitʃɪz ən sɔɹɾ ɪmiɾiətli əpɑn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ - ʃi stɪl bɔɹ ə kʌɾ ɑn əɹ ɑɹm fɹəm wɛɹ ðət sɔɹd hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl əɹ - bʌt lətʃəl sim tə bi seɪvɝɪŋ əɹ taɪm ɪn ðə skɝt.

"No, I doubt they guessed," Lacile replied. She still wore a simple tan blouse and darker brown skirt. Selande had changed back to breeches and sword immediately upon returning - she still bore a cut on her arm from where that sword had tried to kill her - but Lacile seemed to be savoring her time in the skirt.

'ðeɪ bɛɹli sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ ə jus," sɛlən sɛd.

'They barely said anything of use," Selande said.

"jɛs," lətʃəl ɹɪplaɪd, "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ mɪɹli ɪn ðət hæbət. əɹ ɪkskjus ə tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn meɪaɪɡdɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wɑz ə ɹizənəbəl wʌn, maɪ leɪɾi. wi wɝ eɪbəl tə dɪlɪvɝ jəɹ noʊt, ðən də ə lɪɾəl tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ðə mɛn. aɪ tizd aʊɾ ɪnʌf tə bi ʌv səm jus."

"Yes," Lacile replied, "but I think they're merely in that habit. Our excuse of checking on Maighdin and the others was a reasonable one, my Lady. We were able to deliver your note, then do a little chatting with the men. I teased out enough to be of some use."

feɪl ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ðoʊ lətʃəl fɛl kwaɪəɾ əz ðeɪ pæst ə ɡɹum wɝkɪŋ leɪt, bɹʌʃɪŋ daʊn wʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz.

Faile raised an eyebrow, though Lacile fell quiet as they passed a groom working late, brushing down one of the horses.

"ðə waɪtkloʊks ɹɪspɛkt ɡɑləd," lətʃəl sɛd wʌns aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹumz ɪɹʃɑt. "ðoʊ səm ɡɹʌmbəl əbaʊt ðə θɪŋz hiz bɪn tɛlɪŋ ðɛm"

"The Whitecloaks respect Galad," Lacile said once out of the groom's earshot. "Though some grumble about the things he's been telling them"

"wʌt θɪŋz?" feɪl æskt.

"What things?" Faile asked.

"hi wɑns əm tə əlaɪ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl," lətʃəl ɪkspleɪnd.

"He wants them to ally with the Aes Sedai for the Last Battle," Lacile explained.

"ɛniwʌn cʊɾə toʊl jə ðeɪ wəd dɪslaɪk ðəɾ aɪdiə," sɛlən sɛd. "ðeɪɹ waɪtkloʊks!"

"Anyone could have told you they would dislike that idea," Selande said. "They're Whitecloaks!"

"jɛs," feɪl sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪt minz ðət ðɪs ɡɑləɾ ɪz mɔɹ ɹizənəbəl ðən ɪz mɛn. ə jusfəl tɪp, lətʃəl."

"Yes," Faile said, "but it means that this Galad is more reasonable than his men. A useful tip, Lacile."

ðə jʌŋ wʊmən swɛld, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ ʃɔɹt hɛɹ bæk ɪn ə mɑɾəst dʒɛstʃɝ, θɹoʊɪŋ bæk ðə ɹɛd ɹɪbənz ʃi hæd taɪd ðɛɹ. ʃid teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ twaɪs əz mɛni naʊ, sɪns əɹ ʃeɪɾoʊ kæptɪvəɾi.

The young woman swelled, brushing her short hair back in a modest gesture, throwing back the red ribbons she had tied there. She'd taken to wearing twice as many now, since her Shaido captivity.

ʌp əhɛd, ə læŋki fɪɡjɝ stɛp bɪtwin tu ʌv ðə hɔɹsəz. hi hæɾ ə θɪk mʌstæʃ, tæɹɑbənɝ staɪl, ən ðoʊ hi wɑz jʌŋ, hi hæd ði ɛɹ ʌv wʌn u hæd sin mʌtʃ ɪn ɪz laɪf. dænɪl luɪn, ðə mæn ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn naʊ ðət tæm hæd mɪstɪɹiəsli dɪsaɪɾɪd tə dɪpɑɹt. laɪt sɛn ðət tæm wɑz seɪf, wɛɹɛvɝ hid ɡɔn.

Up ahead, a lanky figure stepped between two of the horses. He had a thick mustache, Taraboner style, and though he was young, he had the air of one who had seen much in his life. Dannil Lewin, the man in charge of the Two Rivers men now that Tam had mysteriously decided to depart. Light send that Tam was safe, wherever he'd gone.

"waɪ, dænɪl," feɪl sɛd, "wʌɾ ən ɑd koʊɪnsɪɾəns tə si jə hɪɹ."

"Why, Dannil," Faile said, "what an odd coincidence to see you here."

"koʊɪnsɪɾəns?" hi æskt, skɹætʃɪŋ əɾ ɪz hɛd. hi hɛld ɪz baʊ ɪn wʌn hænd, stæf-laɪk, ðoʊ hi kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɪt, wɛɹi. ə lɑɾ ə pipəl dɪd ðət wɪð ðɛɹ wɛpənz naʊ. "ju æsk mi tə kʌm hɪɹ."

"Coincidence?" he asked, scratching at his head. He held his bow in one hand, staff-like, though he kept glancing at it, wary. A lot of people did that with their weapons now. "You asked me to come here."

"ɪt mʌs bi ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns nʌnðəlɛs," feɪl sɛd, "ɪn keɪs ɛniwʌn æsks. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪf ðət sʌmbɑɾi ɪz maɪ hʌzbənd."

"It must be a coincidence nonetheless," Faile said, "in case anyone asks. Particularly if that somebody is my husband."

"aɪ doʊn laɪk kipɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," dænɪl sɛd, fɔlɪŋ ɪndə stɛp wɪð hɝ.

"I don't like keeping things from Lord Perrin," Dannil said, falling into step with her.

"æn jud pɹəfɝ tə ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ ɪm bi bɪhɛɾɪd baɪ ə ɡɹup ə ɹæbɪd waɪtkloʊks?"

"And you'd prefer to risk letting him be beheaded by a group of rabid Whitecloaks?"

"noʊ. nʌn ə ðə mɛn du."

"No. None of the men do."

"juv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ æskt, ðɛn?"

"You've done what I asked, then?"

dænɪl nɑɾəd. "aɪ spoʊk tə ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild. lɔɹd pɛɹɪn əz ɔlɹɛɾi ɔɹɾɝd əm tə steɪ nɪɹbaɪ, bʌt wi tɔkt. ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd hiɾ əv wivz əɹ ɛɹ ɹɛɾi, ən wɪl ɡɹæb lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ən ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ɪf θɪŋz ɡɛɾ ʌɡli, nil kʌvɝɪŋ ðə ɹitʃɹit. aɪv tɔk tə ðə mɛn fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ə ɡɹup ʌv ɑɹtʃɝz ɪn ðə tʃɹiz wɪl bi ɹɛɾi tə pɹəvaɪɾ ə dɪstʃɹækʃən."

Dannil nodded. "I spoke to Grady and Neald. Lord Perrin has already ordered them to stay nearby, but we talked. Grady said he'd have weaves or Air ready, and will grab Lord Perrin and get out if things get ugly, Neald covering the retreat. I've talked to the men from the Two Rivers. A group of archers in the trees will be ready to provide a distraction."

feɪl nɑɾəd. niðɝ æʃəmən hæd bɪn wundəɾ ɪn ðɪs bʌbəl ʌv ivəl fɔɹtʃənətli. itʃ hæd bɪn kæɹiɪŋ ə naɪf, bʌt ɹɪpɔɹts sɛd ðeɪd lʊkt ət ðə floʊɾɪŋ wɛpənz, ðən nɑnʃəlɑnli weɪv hænz ən blæstəɾ əm fɹəm ði ɛɹ. wən mɛsənʒɝz wɪð nuz ə feɪlz ɝθ-θɹoʊɪŋ tʃɹɪk hæd ɹitʃt ðə sɛkʃən ə kæmp ði æʃəmən hæd bɪn ɪn, ðeɪd faʊn ðɪs ɛɹiə ɪn mʌtʃ lɛs keɪɑs, ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu kæmp ən fɛlɪŋ wɛpənz wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ sɔ ðɛm.

Faile nodded. Neither Asha'man had been wounded in this bubble of evil fortunately. Each had been carrying a knife, but reports said they'd looked at the floating weapons, then nonchalantly waved hands and blasted them from the air. When messengers with news of Faile's earth-throwing trick had reached the section of camp the Asha'man had been in, they'd found this area in much less chaos, Grady and Neald striding through camp and felling weapons wherever they saw them.

pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹizən fəɹ ðə dɪleɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹaɪəl wɑz tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hilɪŋ. bʌɾ ənʌðɝ lɑɹdʒ ɹizən wɑz kəz pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə ɡɪv taɪm tə ðə kæmps smɪθs ən kɹæfsmən tə meɪk ɹɪpleɪsmənt wɛpənz fəɹ ðoʊz u hæd lɔs ðɛɹz, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ðə tʃɹaɪəl tɝn tə ə bæɾəl. ən feɪl wɑz ɪnkɹisɪŋli sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪt wʊd.

Part of the reason for the delay before the trial was to take care of Healing. But another large reason was because Perrin wanted to give time to the camp's smiths and craftsmen to make replacement weapons for those who had lost theirs, just in case the trial turned to a battle. And Faile was increasingly certain that it would.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn woʊn laɪk biɪŋ pʊld əweɪ fɹəm faɪɾɪŋ," dænɪl sɛd. "nɑt wʌn bɪt."

"Lord Perrin won't like being pulled away from fighting," Dannil said. "Not one bit."

"ðæt tɛn kəd tɝn ɪndə ə dɛθ tʃɹæp," feɪl sɛd. "pɛɹɪn kən lid ðə bæɾəl ɪf i wɑns, bʌt fɹəm ə seɪfɝ pəzɪʃən. jəl ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊt."

"That tent could turn into a death trap," Faile said. "Perrin can lead the battle if he wants, but from a safer position. You will get him out."

dænɪl saɪd, bʌt nɑɾəd. "jɛs, maɪ leɪɾi."

Dannil sighed, but nodded. "Yes, my Lady."

pɛɹɪn wɑz lɝnɪŋ nɑt tə fɪɹ jʌŋ bʊl.

Perrin was learning not to fear Young Bull.

stɛp baɪ stɛp, hi lɝn bæləns. ðə wʊlf wən ðə wʊlf wɑz niɾəd; ðə mæn wən ðə mæn wɑz niɾəd. hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi dʒɹɔn ɪndə ðə hʌnt, bʌt kɛp feɪl - hɪz hoʊm - ɪn ɪz maɪnd. hi wɔk ði ɛdʒ ə ðə sɔɹd, bʌɾ itʃ stɛp meɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt.

Step by step, he learned balance. The wolf when the wolf was needed; the man when the man was needed. He let himself be drawn into the hunt, but kept Faile - his home - in his mind. He walked the edge of the sword, but each step made him more confident.

tədeɪ, hi hʌntəd hɑpɝ, waɪli ən ɪkspɪɹiəns pɹeɪ. bʌt jʌŋ bʊl wɑz kwɪk tə lɝn, ən hævɪŋ ðə maɪn ʌv ə mæn ɡeɪv ɪm ædvæntɪdʒɪz. hi kəd θɪŋk laɪk sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ sʌmwʌn, ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt.

Today, he hunted Hopper, wily and experienced prey. But Young Bull was quick to learn, and having the mind of a man gave him advantages. He could think like something, or someone, that he was not.

wɑz ðɪs haʊ noʊm hæd bɪɡʌn? wɛɹ wəd ðɪs pæθ ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ lɛd? ðəɹ wɑz ə sikɹət tə ðɪs, ə sikɹət jʌŋ bʊl hæd tə faɪn fəɹ hɪmsɛlf.

Was this how Noam had begun? Where would this path of understanding lead? There was a secret to this, a secret Young Bull had to find for himself.

hi kəd nɑt feɪl. hi hæd tə lɝn. ɪt sim ðət - sʌmhaʊ - ðə mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt i bɪkeɪm ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, ðə mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl i bɪkeɪm wɪð hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld.

He could not fail. He had to learn. It seemed that - somehow - the more confident he became in the wolf dream, the more comfortable he became with himself in the waking world.

jʌŋ bʊl tʃɑɹdʒ θɹu ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ fɔɹəst. noʊ, ə dʒʌŋɡəl, wɪð hæŋɪŋ vaɪnz ən waɪd- fɹɑndɪd fɝnz. ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ wɑz soʊ θɪk ðəɾ ə ɹæt wəɾ əv tʃɹʌbəl skwizɪŋ θɹu. bʌt jʌŋ bʊl dɪmændəd ðət ðə wɝld oʊpən bɪfɔɹ hɪm. vaɪnz pʊl bæk. ʃɹʌbz bɛnt. fɝnz ɹitʃɹæktəd, laɪk mʌðɝz pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹs.

Young Bull charged through an unfamiliar forest. No, a jungle, with hanging vines and wide- fronded ferns. The underbrush was so thick that a rat would have trouble squeezing through. But Young Bull demanded that the world open before him. Vines pulled back. Shrubs bent. Ferns retracted, like mothers pulling their children out of the way of a galloping horse.

hi kɑt ɡlɪmpsɪz ə hɑpɝ baʊndɪŋ əhɛd. hɪz pɹeɪ vænɪʃt. jʌŋ bʊl dɪdn bɹeɪk peɪs, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ θɹu ðət spɑɾ ən kætʃɪŋ ðə sɛn ə hɑpɝz dɛstəneɪʃən. jʌŋ bʊl ʃɪftəɾ ɑntu ən oʊpən pleɪn wɪð noʊ tʃɹiz ən ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ skɹʌb pætʃɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz pɹeɪ wɑz ə sɪɹiz ə stʃɹikɪŋ blɝz ɪn ðə dɪstəns. jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd, itʃ baʊn kæɹiɪŋ ɪm hʌnʒɹədz ə peɪsɪz.

He caught glimpses of Hopper bounding ahead. His prey vanished. Young Bull didn't break pace, charging through that spot and catching the scent of Hoppers destination. Young Bull shifted onto an open plain with no trees and an unfamiliar scrub patching the ground. His prey was a series of streaking blurs in the distance. Young Bull followed, each bound carrying him hundreds of paces.

wɪðɪn sɛkənz, ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ən ɪnɔɹməs plætoʊ. hɪz pɹeɪ ɹæn dɝɛkli ʌp ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn ʃɛlf. jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌt wɑz "ɹaɪt." hi ɹæn wɪð ðə ɡɹaʊn fɑɹ bɪloʊ əɾ ɪz bæk, noʊz təwɔɹd ðət bɔɪlɪŋ si ʌv blæk klaʊdz. hi lɛpt oʊvɝ klɛfs ɪn ðə ɹɑk, ɹɪkəʃeɪəŋ bɪtwin tu saɪdz ʌv ə ɹɪft, kɹɛstɪŋ ðə tɑp ə ðə plætoʊ.

Within seconds, they approached an enormous plateau. His prey ran directly up the side of the stone shelf. Young Bull followed, ignoring what was "right." He ran with the ground far below at his back, nose toward that boiling sea of black clouds. He leaped over clefts in the rock, ricocheting between two sides of a rift, cresting the top of the plateau.

hɑpɝ ətækt. jʌŋ bʊl wɑz ɹɛɾi. hi ɹoʊld, kʌmɪŋ ʌp ɑn ɔl fɔɹz əz ɪz pɹeɪ lɛpt oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, pæst oʊvɝ ðə klɪfs ɛdʒ, bʌt ðən vænɪʃt ɪn ə flæʃ ən wɑz bæk stændɪŋ ɑn ðə lɪp ə ðə klɪf.

Hopper attacked. Young Bull was ready. He rolled, coming up on all fours as his prey leaped over his head, passed over the cliff's edge, but then vanished in a flash and was back standing on the lip of the cliff.

jʌŋ bʊl bɪkeɪm pɛɹɪn hoʊldɪŋ ə hæmɝ meɪɾ ə sɑft wʊd. sətʃ θɪŋz wɝ pɑsəbəl ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim; ɪf ðə hæmɝ hɪt, ɪt wəd nɑt hɑɹm.

Young Bull became Perrin holding a hammer made of soft wood. Such things were possible in the wolf dream; if the hammer hit, it would not harm.

pɛɹɪn swʌŋ, ði ɛɹ kɹækɪŋ wɪð ðə sʌɾən spiɾ ə hɪz moʊʃən. bʌt hɑpɝ wɑz ikwəli fæst, dɑdʒɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. hi ɹoʊld, ðən lɛpt ət pɛɹɪnz bæk, fæŋz ɡlɪsnɪŋ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ən ʃɪftəd soʊ ðəɾ i wɑz stændɪŋ ə fju fit fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd bɪn. hɑpɝz dʒɔz snæpt oʊpən ɛɹ, ən pɛɹɪn swʌŋ ɪz hæmɝ əɡɛn.

Perrin swung, the air cracking with the sudden speed of his motion. But Hopper was equally fast, dodging out of the way. He rolled, then leaped at Perrin's back, fangs glistening. Perrin growled and shifted so that he was standing a few feet from where he had been. Hopper's jaws snapped open air, and Perrin swung his hammer again.

hɑpɝ wɑz sʌɾənli ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn ə dip mɪst. pɛɹɪnz hæmɝ slæm daʊn θɹu ɪt, hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɪt baʊnst ɔf. hi kɝst, spɪnɪŋ. ɪn ðə fɑɡ, hi kʊdn si, kʊdn kætʃ hɑpɝz sɛnt.

Hopper was suddenly shrouded in a deep mist. Perrin's hammer slammed down through it, hitting the ground. It bounced off. He cursed, spinning. In the fog, he couldn't see, couldn't catch Hopper's scent.

ə ʃædoʊ muvd ɪn ðə mɪst ən pɛɹɪn lʌnʒd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə pæɾɝn ɪn ði ɛɹ. hi spʌn ən faʊnd ʃædoʊz muvɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə ʃeɪps ʌv wʊlvz, mɛn, ən ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz i kʊdn si.

A shadow moved in the mist and Perrin lunged, but it was only a pattern in the air. He spun and found shadows moving all around him. The shapes of wolves, men, and other creatures he couldn't see.

meɪk ðə wɝl jʊɹz, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

Make the world yours, Young Bull, Hopper sent.

pɛɹɪn foʊkəst, θɪŋkɪŋ ə dʒɹaɪ ɛɹ. ʌv ðə mʌsti sɛn ə dʌst. ðət wɑz wʌt ði ɛɹ ʃəd bi laɪk, ɪn ən æɹəd lændskeɪp laɪk ðɪs.

Perrin focused, thinking of dry air. Of the musty scent of dust. That was what the air should be like, in an arid landscape like this.

noʊ. ɪt wɑznt wʌt ði ɛɹ ʃəd bi laɪk. ɪt wɑz haʊ ði ɛɹ wɑz ɪz maɪnd, hɪz wɪl, hɪz filɪŋz slæmd əɡɛnst sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. hi pʊʃt θɹu.

No. It wasn't what the air should be like. It was how the air was\ His mind, his will, his feelings slammed against something else. He pushed through.

ðə mɪsts vænɪʃt, ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə hit. hɑpɝ sæɾ ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ.

The mists vanished, evaporating in the heat. Hopper sat on his haunches a short distance away.

ɡʊd, ðə wʊlf sɛnt. jə lɝn. hi ɡlænst saɪdweɪz, lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə nɔɹθ, simɪŋ dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ sʌmθɪŋ. ðən i wɑz ɡɔn.

Good, the wolf sent. You learn. He glanced sideways, looking toward the north, seeming distracted by something. Then he was gone.

pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ɪz sɛn ən fɑloʊd tə ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd. hɑpɝ dæʃt əlɔŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ vaɪəlɪt doʊm. ðeɪ dʒʌmp bæk tə ðɪs pleɪs fɹikwənli tə si ɪf ðə doʊm ɛvɝ vænɪʃt. soʊ fɑɹ, ɪt hæd nɑt.

Perrin caught his scent and followed to the Jehannah Road. Hopper dashed along outside the strange violet dome. They jumped back to this place frequently to see if the dome ever vanished. So far, it had not.

pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud ðə tʃeɪs. wɑz ðə doʊm mɛn tə tʃɹæp wʊlvz ɪnsaɪd?

Perrin continued the chase. Was the dome meant to trap wolves inside?

bʌɾ ɪf ðət wɑz ðə keɪs, waɪ hæd sleɪɝ nɑt spɹʌŋ ɪz tʃɹæp ət dʒɹæɡən-maʊnt, wɛɹ soʊ mɛni wʊlvz hæd fəɹ səm ɹizən ɡæðɝd?

But if that was the case, why had Slayer not sprung his trap at Dragon-mount, where so many wolves had for some reason gathered?

pɝhæps ðə doʊm hæɾ ənʌðɝ pɝpəs. pɛɹɪn mɛmɝaɪzd ə fju noʊɾəbəl ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃənz əlɔŋ ðə pɝɪməɾɝ ə ðə doʊm, ðən fɑloʊd hɑpɝ tə ə loʊ ʃɛlf ə ɹɑk. ðə wʊlf lɛp fɹəm ɪt, vænɪʃɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ, ən pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd.

Perhaps the dome had another purpose. Perrin memorized a few notable rock formations along the perimeter of the dome, then followed Hopper to a low shelf of rock. The wolf leaped from it, vanishing in midair, and Perrin followed.

hi kɑt ðə sɛn ə hɑpɝz dɛstəneɪʃən ɪn mɪdʒəmp, ðən tʊk hɪmsɛlf ðɛɹ, stɪl ɪn moʊʃən.

He caught the scent of Hopper's destination in midjump, then took himself there, still in motion.

hi əpɪɹɾ əbaʊt tu fiɾ əbʌv ə ʃɪmɝɪŋ blu ɪkspæns. stʌnd, hi fɛl ən splæʃt ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ.

He appeared about two feet above a shimmering blue expanse. Stunned, he fell and splashed into the water.

hi swæm fɹæntəkəli, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ. hɑpɝ stʊɾ ɑn tɑp ə ðə wɔɾɝ, bɛɹɪŋ ə wʊlfɪʃ ɪkspɹɛʃən ə dɪsəpɹuvəl. nɑt ɡʊd, ðə wʊlf æɾəd. jə stɪl nid tə lɝn.

He swam frantically, dropping his hammer. Hopper stood on top of the water, bearing a wolfish expression of disapproval. Not good, the wolf added. You still need to learn.

pɛɹɪn spʌɾɝd.

Perrin sputtered.

ðə si ɡɹu tɛmpɛstʃuəs, bʌt hɑpɝ sæt plɑtʃədli əpɑn ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ weɪvz. əɡɛn i ɡlæns nɔɹθwɝd, bʌt ðən tɝn bæk tə pɛɹɪn. wɔɾɝ tʃɹʌbəlz ju, jʌŋ bʊl.

The sea grew tempestuous, but Hopper sat placidly upon the rolling waves. Again he glanced northward, but then turned back to Perrin. Water troubles you, Young Bull.

"aɪ wɑz dʒʌst sɝpɹaɪzd," pɛɹɪn sɛd, swɪmɪŋ hɑɹd.

"I was just surprised," Perrin said, swimming hard.

waɪ?

Why?

"bɪkɔz aɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛk ðɪs!"

"Because I didn't expect this!"

waɪ ɪkspɛkt? hɑpɝ sɛnt. wən jə fɑloʊ ənʌðɝ, jə kəɾ ɛn ʌp ɛniwɛɹ.

Why expect? Hopper sent. When you follow another, you could end up anywhere.

"aɪ noʊ." pɛɹɪn spæɾ aʊɾ ə maʊθfʊl ʌv wɔɾɝ. hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, ðən ɪmædʒən hɪmsɛlf stændɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ laɪk hɑpɝ. blɛsədli, hi ɹoʊz aʊɾ ə ðə si tə stæn ətɑp ɪts sɝfəs. ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɛnseɪʃən, ðə si ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ bɪniθ hɪm.

"I know." Perrin spat out a mouthful of water. He gritted his teeth, then imagined himself standing on the water like Hopper. Blessedly, he rose out of the sea to stand atop its surface. It was a strange sensation, the sea undulating beneath him.

jəl nɑt dɪfit sleɪɝ laɪk ðɪs, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

You will not defeat Slayer like this, Hopper sent.

"ðɛn əl kip lɝnɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Then I will keep learning," Perrin said.

ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl taɪm.

There is little time.

"aɪ wɪl lɝn mɔɹ kwɪkli."

"I will learn more quickly."

kən ju?

Can you?

"wi hæv noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs."

"We have no other choice."

jə kəd tʃuz nɑt tə faɪt hɪm.

You could choose not to fight him.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "du wi ɹʌn fɹəm əɹ pɹeɪ? ɪf wi du, ðəl hʌn əs ɪnstɛd. əl feɪs hɪm, ən aɪ nid tə bi pɹipɛɹd."

Perrin shook his head. "Do we run from our prey? If we do, they'll hunt us instead. I will face him, and I need to be prepared."

ðəɹ ɪz ə weɪ. ðə wʊlf smɛld ʌv wɝi.

There is a way. The wolf smelled of worry.

"aɪl də wʌɾ aɪ hæv tə."

"I'll do what I have to."

fɑloʊ. hɑpɝ vænɪʃt, ən pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd sɛnt: ɹɛfjus ən mʌd, bɝnɪŋ wʊɾ ən koʊl. pipəl.

Follow. Hopper vanished, and Perrin caught an unexpected scent: refuse and mud, burning wood and coal. People.

pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf ətɑp ə bɪldɪŋ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. hi hæd vɪzəɾəd ðɪs sɪɾi oʊnli wʌns, ən bɹifli, ən siɪŋ ðə bjuɾəfəl ɪnɝ sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ ɪm - eɪntʃən bɪldɪŋz, doʊmz ən spaɪɹz ɹaɪzɪŋ ətɑp ðə hɪl laɪk mədʒɛstɪk paɪnz ətɑp ə kɹaʊn maʊntən - ɡeɪv ɪm pɔz. hi wɑz nɪɹ ði oʊld wɔl, bɪɑnd wɪtʃ spɹɛd ðə nu sɪɾi.

Perrin shifted and found himself atop a building in Caemlyn. He had visited this city only once, and briefly, and seeing the beautiful Inner City before him - ancient buildings, domes and spires rising atop the hill like majestic pines atop a crowned mountain - gave him pause. He was near the old wall, beyond which spread the New City.

hɑpɝ sæɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə bjuɾəfəl sɪɾi. mʌtʃ ə ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf wɑz sɛd tə bi oʊɡiɝ-bɪlt, ən pɛɹɪn kəd bɪliv ɪt, wɪð ðət mɑɹvələs bjuɾi. tɑɹ vəlɑn wɑz sɛd tə bi mɔɹ ɡɹæn ðən keɪɛmlɪn. pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɹʌbəl bɪlivɪŋ ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl.

Hopper sat at his side, looking over the beautiful city. Much of the city itself was said to be Ogier-built, and Perrin could believe it, with that marvelous beauty. Tar Valon was said to be more grand than Caemlyn. Perrin had trouble believing that was possible.

"waɪ ɑɹ wi hɪɹ?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Why are we here?" Perrin asked.

mɛn dʒɹim hɪɹ, hɑpɝ ɹɪplaɪd.

Men dream here, Hopper replied.

ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, ðeɪ dɪd. hɪɹ, ðə pleɪs wɑz ɛmpti. ɪt wɑz laɪɾ ɪnʌf tə bi deɪ, dɪspaɪt ðət stɔɹm oʊvɝhɛd, ən pɛɹɪn fɛl ðəɹ ʃəd bi pipəl kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹits. wɪmən, ɡoʊɪŋ tə ən fɹəm mɑɹkət. noʊbəlz ətɑp hɔɹsəz. wæɡənz bɛɹɪŋ bæɹəlz ʌv eɪl ən sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn. tʃɪlʒɹən skæmpɝɪŋ, slɪpfmɡɝz sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ mɑɹks, wɝkɝz ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, ɛntɝpɹaɪzɪŋ hɔkɝz ɔfɝɪŋ mit paɪz tə ðɛm ɔl.

In the real world, they did. Here, the place was empty. It was light enough to be day, despite that storm overhead, and Perrin felt there should be people crowding the streets. Women, going to and from market. Nobles atop horses. Wagons bearing barrels of ale and sacks of grain. Children scampering, slipfmgers searching for marks, workers replacing paving stones, enterprising hawkers offering meat pies to them all.

ɪnstɛd, ðəɹ wɝ hɪns. ʃædoʊz. ə fɔlən hæŋkɝtʃɪf ɑn ðə stʃɹit. dɔɹz ðət wɝ oʊpən wʌn moʊmənt, ðən kloʊz ðə nɛkst. ə θɹoʊn hɔɹsʃu stɪkɪŋ fɹəm ðə mʌɾ ʌv ən æliweɪ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɔl ə ðə pipəl hæd bɪn wɪskt əweɪ, snætʃt baɪ feɪdz əɹ səm mɑnstɝ fɹəm ə ɡlimənz dɑɹk teɪl.

Instead, there were hints. Shadows. A fallen handkerchief on the street. Doors that were open one moment, then closed the next. A thrown horseshoe sticking from the mud of an alleyway. It was as if all of the people had been whisked away, snatched by Fades or some monster from a gleemans dark tale.

ə wʊmən əpɪɹd moʊməntɛɹəli bɪloʊ. ʃi wɔɹ ə bjuɾəfəl ɡɹin ən ɡoʊl dʒɹɛs. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə stʃɹit, aɪz ɡleɪzd oʊvɝ, ðən wɑz ɡɔn. pipəl dɪɾ əkeɪʒənəli əpɪɹ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. pɛɹɪn fɪɡjɝɾ ɪt mʌs hæpən tə ðɛm wən ðeɪ wɝ əslip, pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ nætʃɹəl dʒɹimz.

A woman appeared momentarily below. She wore a beautiful green and gold dress. She stared at the street, eyes glazed over, then was gone. People did occasionally appear in the wolf dream. Perrin figured it must happen to them when they were asleep, part of their natural dreams.

ðɪs pleɪs, hɑpɝ sɛd, ɪz nɑɾ oʊnli ə pleɪs ʌv wʊlvz. ɪts ə pleɪs ʌv ɔl.

This place, Hopper said, is not only a place of wolves. It is a place of all.

"ʌv ɔl?" pɛɹɪn æskt, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə ɹuftaɪlz.

"Of all?" Perrin asked, sitting down on the rooftiles.

ɔl soʊlz noʊ ðɪs pleɪs, hɑpɝ sɛd. ðeɪ kʌm hɪɹ wən ðeɪ ɹitʃ fəɹ ɪt.

All souls know this place, Hopper said. They come here when they reach for it.

"wɛn ðəɹ dʒɹimɪŋ."

"When they're dreaming."

jɛs, hɑpɝ sɛd, laɪɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðə fɪɹ-dʒɹimz ə mɛn ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ. soʊ vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ.

Yes, Hopper said, lying down beside him. The fear-dreams of men are strong. So very strong.

səmtaɪmz, ðoʊz tɛɹəbəl dʒɹimz kʌm hɪɹ. ðət sɛndɪŋ wɑz ən ɪnɔɹməs wʊlf, ðə saɪz ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ, nɑkɪŋ əsaɪd mʌtʃ smɔlɝ wʊlvz u tʃɹaɪd tə snæp ət hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɛn ə tɛɹɝ ən dɛθ əbaʊt ðə wʊlf. laɪk ... ə naɪtmɛɹ.

Sometimes, those terrible dreams come here. That sending was an enormous wolf, the size of a building, knocking aside much smaller wolves who tried to snap at him. There was a scent of terror and death about the wolf. Like ... a nightmare.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli.

Perrin nodded slowly.

mɛni wʊlvz əv bɪn kɑɾ ɪn ðə peɪnz ə ðiz fɪɹ-dʒɹimz. ðeɪ əpɪɹ mɔɹ kɑmənli wɛɹ mɛn maɪt wɔk, ðoʊ ðə dʒɹim lɪvz wɪθaʊt ðoʊz u kɹieɪɾəd ɪt.

Many wolves have been caught in the pains of these fear-dreams. They appear more commonly where men might walk, though the dream lives without those who created it.

hɑpɝ lʊkt ət pɛɹɪn. hʌntɪŋ ɪn ðə fɪɹ-dʒɹimz wɪl titʃ jə stʃɹɛŋkθ. bʌt jə maɪt daɪ. ɪts vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs.

Hopper looked at Perrin. Hunting in the fear-dreams will teach you strength. But you might die. It is very dangerous.

"aɪ doʊn əv taɪm tə bi seɪf ɛnimɔɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "lɛts də ɪt."

"I don't have time to be safe anymore," Perrin said. "Let's do it."

hɑpɝ dɪdn æsk ɪf i wɑz sɝɾən. hi dʒʌmp daʊn tə ðə stʃɹit, ən pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, lændɪŋ sɔfli. hɑpɝ bɪɡæn tə loʊp fɔɹwɝd, soʊ pɝ-ɹɪn bɹoʊk ɪndə ə dʒɑɡ.

Hopper didn't ask if he was certain. He jumped down to the street, and Perrin followed, landing softly. Hopper began to lope forward, so Per-rin broke into a jog.

"haʊ də wi faɪn ðɛm?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"How do we find them?" Perrin asked.

smɛl fɪɹ, hɑpɝ sɛnt. tɛɹɝ.

Smell fear, Hopper sent. Terror.

pɛɹɪn kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn dipli. dʒʌst əz dɔɹz flæʃt oʊpən ən kloʊzd, ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim i kəd səmtaɪmz smɛl θɪŋz ðəɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ɡɔn. mʌsti wɪntɝ pəteɪɾoʊz. ðə dʌŋ ʌv ə pæsɪŋ hɔɹs.

Perrin closed his eyes, breathing in deeply. Just as doors flashed open and closed, in the wolf dream he could sometimes smell things there for a moment, then gone. Musty winter potatoes. The dung of a passing horse.

ə paɪ, beɪkɪŋ.

A pie, baking.

wən i oʊpən ɪz aɪz, hi sɔ nʌn ə ðiz θɪŋz. ðeɪ wɝn ɹɪli ðɛɹ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlmoʊst wɝ. ðeɪ kəɾ əv bɪn.

When he opened his eyes, he saw none of these things. They weren't really there, but they almost were. They could have been.

ðɛɹ, hɑpɝ sɛd, vænɪʃɪŋ. pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, əpɪɹɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə wʊlf aʊtsaɪɾ ʌv ə nɛɹoʊ æliweɪ. ɪnsaɪd, ɪt lʊk tu dɑɹk tə bi nætʃɹəl.

There, Hopper said, vanishing. Perrin followed, appearing beside the wolf outside of a narrow alleyway. Inside, it looked too dark to be natural.

ɡoʊ ɪn, hɑpɝ sɛd. jəl nɑt læs lɔŋ jəɹ fɝs taɪm. əl kʌm fəɹ ju. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪts nɑt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪts fɔls.

Go in, Hopper said. You will not last long your first time. I will come for you. Remember it is not. Remember it is false.

filɪŋ wɝid, bʌt dɪtɝmənd, pɛɹɪn stɛpt ɪndə ði æliweɪ. ðə wɔlz tə iðɝ saɪd wɝ blæk, əz ɪf ðeɪd bɪn peɪntəd. oʊnli . . . ðiz wɔlz wɝ tu dɑɹk tə bi peɪntəd. wɑz ðəɾ ə tʌft ʌv ɡɹæs bɪniθ ɪz fʊt? ðə skaɪ əbʌv hæd stɑp bɔɪlɪŋ, ən i θɔɾ i kəd si stɑɹz pikɪŋ daʊn. ə peɪl mun, fɑɹ tu lɑɹdʒ, əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ, ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn klaʊdz. ɪt ɡeɪv ə koʊld ɡloʊ, laɪk aɪs.

Feeling worried, but determined, Perrin stepped into the alleyway. The walls to either side were black, as if they'd been painted. Only . . . these walls were too dark to be painted. Was that a tuft of grass beneath his foot? The sky above had stopped boiling, and he thought he could see stars peeking down. A pale moon, far too large, appeared in the sky, shrouded in clouds. It gave a cold glow, like ice.

hi wɑzn ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɛnimɔɹ. hi tɝn əbaʊt, əlɑɹmd, tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə fɔɹəst. ðə tʃɹiz hæd θɪk tʃɹʌŋks ən wɝ ə noʊ spiʃiz i kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. ðɛɹ bɹæntʃəz wɝ neɪkəd. ðə bɑɹk wɑz ə feɪnt ɡɹeɪ, lɪt baɪ ðə fæntəm laɪɾ əbʌv, ən lʊk laɪk boʊn.

He wasn't in the city anymore. He turned about, alarmed, to find himself in a forest. The trees had thick trunks and were of no species he could recognize. Their branches were naked. The bark was a faint gray, lit by the phantom light above, and looked like bone.

hi niɾəd tə ɡɛt bæk tə ðə sɪɾi! aʊɾ ə ðɪs tɛɹəbəl pleɪs. hi tɝn ɝaʊnd.

He needed to get back to the city! Out of this terrible place. He turned around.

sʌmθɪŋ flæʃt ɪn ðə naɪt, ən i spʌn. "huz ðɛɹ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd.

Something flashed in the night, and he spun. "Who's there!" he shouted.

ə wʊmən bɝs fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ə mæd skɹæmbəl. ʃi wɔɹ ə lus waɪt ɹoʊb, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə ʃɪft, ən ʃi hæd lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ʃi sɔ hɪm ən fɹoʊz, ðən tɝn ən meɪɾ əz ɪf tə ɹʌn ɪn ə dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃən.

A woman burst from the darkness, running in a mad scramble. She wore a loose white robe, little more than a shift, and she had long dark hair streaming behind her. She saw him and froze, then turned and made as if to run in a different direction.

pɛɹɪn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf, snætʃɪŋ əɹ hænd, pʊlɪŋ əɹ bæk. ʃi stʃɹʌɡəld, fit mɑɹɪŋ ðə loʊmi dɑɹk ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl əweɪ. ʃi wɑz ɡæspɪŋ. ɪn ən aʊt. ɪn ən aʊt. ʃi smɛl fɹæntɪk.

Perrin cut her off, snatching her hand, pulling her back. She struggled, feet marring the loamy dark ground beneath as she tried to pull away. She was gasping. In and out. In and out. She smelled frantic.

aɪ nid tə noʊ ðə weɪ aʊt!" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wi hæv tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə sɪɾi."

I need to know the way out!" Perrin said. "We have to return to the city."

ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. "hiz kʌmɪŋ," ʃi hɪst. hɝ hæn slɪp fɹəm ɪz ən ʃi ɹæn, vænɪʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt, ðə dɑɹknəs ɛnfoʊldɪŋ əɹ laɪk ə ʃɹaʊd. pɛɹɪn tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, hæn aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt.

She met his eyes. "He's coming," she hissed. Her hand slipped from his and she ran, vanishing into the night, the darkness enfolding her like a shroud. Perrin took a step forward, hand outstretched.

hi hɝd sʌmθɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi tɝn sloʊli tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ɪnɔɹməs. ə lumɪŋ ʃædoʊ ðət sʌkt ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ðə θɪŋ sim tə dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ əweɪ, əbzɔɹbɪŋ ɪz vɛɹi laɪf ən wɪl.

He heard something behind him. He turned slowly to find something enormous. A looming shadow that sucked in the moonlight. The thing seemed to draw breath away, absorbing his very life and will.

ðə θɪŋ ɹɪɹɾ ʌp tɔlɝ. ɪt wɑz tɔlɝ ðən ðə tʃɹiz, ə hʌlkɪŋ mɑnstɝ wɪð ɑɹmz əz θɪk əz bæɹəlz, ɪts feɪs ən bɑɾi lɔst ɪn ʃædoʊ. ɪɾ oʊpən dip ɹɛɾ aɪz, laɪk tu hjudʒ koʊlz flɛɹɪŋ tə laɪf.

The thing reared up taller. It was taller than the trees, a hulking monster with arms as thick as barrels, its face and body lost in shadow. It opened deep red eyes, like two huge coals flaring to life.

/ nid tə faɪɾ ɪt! pɛɹɪn θɔt, hæmɝ əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænd. hi tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ðən θɔt bɛɾɝ ʌv ɪt. laɪt! ðət θɪŋ wɑz ɪnɔɹməs. hi kʊdn faɪɾ ɪt, nɑɾ aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən laɪk ðɪs.

/ need to fight it! Perrin thought, hammer appearing in his hand. He took a step forward, then thought better of it. Light! That thing was enormous. He couldn't fight it, not out in the open like this.

hi niɾəd kʌvɝ i tɝn ən ɹæn θɹu ðə hɑstəl wʊdz. ðə θɪŋ fɑloʊd. hi kəd hɪɹ ɪt snæpɪŋ bɹæntʃəz, ɪts fʊtstɛps meɪkɪŋ ði ɝθ ʃeɪk əhɛɾ ə hɪm, hi sɔ ðə wʊmən, hɝ θɪn waɪt ɡaʊn sloʊɪŋ əɹ əz ɪt kɑɾ ɑn ə bɹæntʃ. ʃi pʊl fɹi ən kəntɪnjud tə ɹʌn.

He needed cover He turned and ran through the hostile woods. The thing followed. He could hear it snapping branches, its footsteps making the earth shake Ahead of him, he saw the woman, her thin white gown slowing her as it caught on a branch. She pulled free and continued to run.

ðə kɹitʃɝ lumd. ɪt wəd kætʃ hɪm, kənsum hɪm, dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm! hi jɛl fəɹ ðə wʊmən, ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt təwɔɹd hɝ. ʃi ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm, ən tʃɹɪpt.

The creature loomed. It would catch him, consume him, destroy him! He yelled for the woman, reaching out toward her. She glanced over her shoulder at him, and tripped.

pɛɹɪn kɝst. hi skɹæmbəl tə hɝ saɪd, tə hɛlp əɹ ʌp. bʌt ðə θɪŋ wɑz soʊ kloʊz!

Perrin cursed. He scrambled to her side, to help her up. But the thing was so close!

ɪt wɑz ə faɪt, ðɛn. hɪz hɑɹt wɑz θʌmpɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz ə wʊdlɑɹk pɛkɪŋ ə tʃɹi. hænz swɛɾi, hi tɝnd, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ tə feɪs ðə tɛɹəbəl θɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. hi pleɪs hɪmsɛlf bɪtwin ɪɾ ən ðə wʊmən.

It was a fight, then. His heart was thumping as quickly as a woodlark pecking a tree. Hands sweaty, he turned, gripping his hammer to face the terrible thing behind. He placed himself between it and the woman.

ɪt ɹɪɹɾ ʌp, ɡɹoʊɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ, ðoʊz ɹɛɾ aɪz bleɪzɪŋ wɪð faɪɝ. laɪt! hi kʊdn faɪt ðæt, kəd hi? hi niɾəd ən ɛdʒ ə səm kaɪnd. "wʌɾ ɪz ðət θɪŋ?" hi dɛspɝətli æskt ə ðə wʊmən. "waɪ dʌz ɪt tʃeɪs ʌs?"

It reared up, growing larger, those red eyes blazing with fire. Light! He couldn't fight that, could he? He needed an edge of some kind. "What is that thing?" he desperately asked of the woman. "Why does it chase us?"

"ɪts hɪm" ʃi hɪst. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"It's him" she hissed. "The Dragon Reborn."

pɛɹɪn fɹoʊz. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. bʌt. . . bʌt ðət wɑz ɹænd. ɪts ə naɪtmɛɹ, hi ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf.

Perrin froze. The Dragon Reborn. But. . . but that was Rand. It's a nightmare, he reminded himself.

nʌn ə ðɪs ɪz ɹil. aɪ kæn lɛt maɪsɛlf bi kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ɪt!

None of this is real. I can't let myself be caught up in it!

ðə ɡɹaʊn tʃɹɛmbəld, əz ɪf moʊnɪŋ. hi kəd fil ðə hiɾ ə ðə mɑnstɝz aɪz. ə skɹæmbəlɪŋ saʊn keɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪn əz ðə wʊmən ɹæn, livɪŋ hɪm.

The ground trembled, as if moaning. He could feel the heat of the monster's eyes. A scrambling sound came from behind as the woman ran, leaving him.

pɛɹɪn stʊɾ ʌp, lɛɡz ʃeɪkɪŋ, ɛvɹi ɪnstɪŋkt kɹaɪɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə ɹʌn. bʌt noʊ. hi kʊdn faɪɾ ɪt, iðɝ. hi kəd nɑɾ æksɛp ðɪs əz ɹil.

Perrin stood up, legs shaking, every instinct crying for him to run. But no. He couldn't fight it, either. He could not accept this as real.

ə wʊlf haʊld, ðən lɛpt ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ. hɑpɝ sim tə pʊʃ bæk ðə dɑɹknəs. ðə kɹitʃɝ bɛn daʊn təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn, ɹitʃɪŋ ə mæsɪv hæn əz ɪf tə kɹʌʃ hɪm.

A wolf howled, then leaped into the clearing. Hopper seemed to push back the darkness. The creature bent down toward Perrin, reaching a massive hand as if to crush him.

ðɪs wɑz ən æli.

This was an alley.

ɪnsaɪɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn.

Inside of Caemlyn.

ɪt wɑzn ɹil.

It wasn't real.

ɪt wɑz nɑt.

It was not.

ðə dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn əm feɪɾəd. ði ɪnɔɹməs dɑɹk ʃædoʊ kɹitʃɝ wɔɹpt ɪn ði ɛɹ, laɪk ə pis ə klɔθ biɪŋ stʃɹɛtʃt. ðə mun vænɪʃt.

The darkness around them faded. The enormous dark shadow creature warped in the air, like a piece of cloth being stretched. The moon vanished.

ə smɔl pɑkəɾ ʌv ɡɹaʊnd - ðə dɝɾi, tʃɹæmpəld ɝθ ʌv ən æli - əpɪɹɾ ət ðɛɹ fit.

A small pocket of ground - the dirty, trampled earth of an alley - appeared at their feet.

ðɛn, wɪð ə snæp, ðə dʒɹim wɑz ɡɔn. pɛɹɪn stʊɾ ɪn ði æli əɡɛn, hɑpɝ əɾ ɪz saɪd, noʊ saɪn ə ðə fɔɹəst əɹ ðə tɛɹəbəl kɹitʃɝ ðət sʌmwʌn hæd vjuɾ əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Then, with a snap, the dream was gone. Perrin stood in the alley again, Hopper at his side, no sign of the forest or the terrible creature that someone had viewed as the Dragon Reborn.

pɛɹɪn ɛksheɪl sloʊli. swɛt dʒɹɪp fɹəm ɪz bɹaʊ. hi ɹitʃt ʌp tə waɪp ɪɾ əweɪ, ðən wɪl ðə swɛɾ əweɪ ɪnstɛd.

Perrin exhaled slowly. Sweat dripped from his brow. He reached up to wipe it away, then willed the sweat away instead.

hɑpɝ vænɪʃt, ən pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, faɪndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə seɪm ɹuftɑp əz bɪfɔɹ. hi sæt daʊn. mɪɹli θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðət ʃædoʊ meɪɾ ɪm ʃɪvɝ. "ɪt fɛl soʊ ɹil," hi sɛd. "ə pis ə mi nu ɪt wɑz ə naɪtmɛɹ. aɪ kʊdn hɛlp bʌt tʃɹaɪ tə faɪt, əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə ɹʌn. wən aɪ dɪɾ iðɝ, ɪt ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ, dɪdn ɪt? kəz aɪ æksɛptɪɾ ɪt wɑz ɹil?"

Hopper vanished, and Perrin followed, finding himself on the same rooftop as before. He sat down. Merely thinking of that shadow made him shiver. "It felt so real," he said. "A piece of me knew it was a nightmare. I couldn't help but try to fight, or try to run. When I did either, it grew stronger, didn't it? Because I accepted it was real?"

jɛs. jə mʌs nɑt bɪliv wʌt jə si.

Yes. You must not believe what you see.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ wɑz ə wʊmən ɪn ðɛɹ. pɑɹɾ ə ðə dʒɹim? ʃi wɑzn ɹil iðɝ?"

Perrin nodded. "There was a woman in there. Part of the dream? She wasn't real either?"

jɛs.

Yes.

"meɪbi ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u dʒɹimd ɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə wʌn hævɪŋ ði ɝɪdʒənəl naɪtmɛɹ, kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ɪɾ ən tʃɹæp hɪɹ ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz."

"Maybe she was the one who dreamed it," Perrin said. "The one having the original nightmare, caught up in it and trapped here in the World of Dreams."

mɛn u dʒɹim də nɑt steɪ hɪɹ lɔŋ, hɑpɝ sɛnt. tə hɪm, ðət wɑz ði ɛn ə ðə dɪskʌʃən.

Men who dream do not stay here long, Hopper sent. To him, that was the end of the discussion.

jə wɝ stʃɹɔŋ, jʌŋ bʊl. jə dɪd wɛl. hi smɛl pɹaʊd.

You were strong, Young Bull. You did well. He smelled proud.

"ɪt hɛlpt wən ʃi kɔl ðə θɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðət ʃoʊɾ ɪt wɑzn ɹil. hɛlp mi bɪliv ɪt wɑznt."

"It helped when she called the thing the Dragon Reborn. That showed it wasn't real. Helped me believe it wasn't."

jə dɪd wɛl, fulɪʃ kʌb, hɑpɝ ɹɪpiɾɪd. pɝhæps jə kən lɝn.

You did well, foolish cub, Hopper repeated. Perhaps you can learn.

"oʊnli ɪf aɪ kip pɹæktəsɪŋ. wi nid tə də ðəɾ əɡɛn. kən jə faɪn ənʌðɝ?"

"Only if I keep practicing. We need to do that again. Can you find another?"

jɛs, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz naɪtmɛɹz wən jəɹ kaɪn ɪz nɪɹ. ɔlweɪz. ðə wʊlf tɝnd nɔɹθwɝɾ əɡɛn, haʊɛvɝ. pɛɹɪn hæd θɔt ðət ðə θɪŋ ðət hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ ɪm ɝliɝ wɑz ðə dʒɹimz, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn sim tə hæv bɪn ðə keɪs.

Yes, Hopper sent. There are always nightmares when your kind is near. Always. The wolf turned northward again, however. Perrin had thought that the thing that had been distracting him earlier was the dreams, but it didn't seem to have been the case.

wʌɾ ɪz ʌp ðɛɹ?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə kip lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd?"

What is up there?" Perrin asked. "What is it you keep looking toward?"

ɪt kʌmz, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

It comes, Hopper sent.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

ðə læs hʌnt. ɪt bɪɡɪnz. əɹ ɪt dʌz nɑt.

The Last Hunt. It begins. Or it does not.

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd, stændɪŋ. "ju min . . . ɹaɪt naʊ?"

Perrin frowned, standing. "You mean . . . right now?"

ðə dɪsɪʒən wɪl bi meɪd. sun. wʌt dɪsɪʒən?" hɑpɝz sɛndɪŋz wɝ kənfjuzɪŋ, ən i kʊdn dɪsaɪfɝ ðɛm. laɪɾ ən dɑɹknəs, ə vɔɪɾ ən faɪɝ, ə koʊlnəs ən ə tɛɹi-bəl, tɛɹəbəl hit. mɪkst wɪð wʊlvz haʊlɪŋ, kɔlɪŋ, lɛndɪŋ stʃɹɛŋkθ.

The decision will be made. Soon. What decision?" Hopper's sendings were confusing, and he couldn't decipher them. Light and darkness, a void and fire, a coldness and a terri-ble, terrible heat. Mixed with wolves howling, calling, lending strength.

kʌm. hɑpɝ stʊd, lʊkɪŋ tə ðə nɔɹθist.

Come. Hopper stood, looking to the northeast.

hɑpɝ vænɪʃt. pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ æftɝ hɪm, əpɪɹɪŋ loʊ daʊn ɑn ðə sloʊps ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, bɪsaɪɾ ən aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ ə stoʊn.

Hopper vanished. Perrin shifted after him, appearing low down on the slopes of the Dragonmount, beside an outcropping of stone.

"laɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ɪn ɑ. ðə stɔɹm ðət hæd bɪn bɹuɪŋ fəɹ mʌnθs hæd kʌm tə ə hɛd. ə mæsɪv blæk θʌndɝhɛd dɑməneɪɾəd ðə skaɪ, kʌvɝɪŋ ðə tɑp ə ðə maʊntən. ɪt spʌn sloʊli ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ɪnɔɹməs vɔɹɾɛks ə blæknəs, ɪmɪɾɪŋ boʊls ə laɪtnɪŋ ðət kɑn-nɛktɪd tə ðə klaʊdz əbʌv. ɪn ʌðɝ pɑɹts ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ðə klaʊdz wɝ tɛmpɛstʃuəs, jɛt dɪstənt. ðɪs fɛlt ɪmiɾiət.

"Light," Perrin said softly, looking up in awe. The storm that had been brewing for months had come to a head. A massive black thunderhead dominated the sky, covering the top of the mountain. It spun slowly in the air, an enormous vortex of blackness, emitting bolts of lightning that con-nected to the clouds above. In other parts of the wolf dream the clouds were tempestuous, yet distant. This felt immediate.

ðɪs wɑz ... ðə foʊkəs ə sʌmθɪŋ. pɛɹɪn kəd fil ɪt. ɔfən, ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ɹəflɛktəd θɪŋz ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒ əɹ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd weɪz.

This was ... the focus of something. Perrin could feel it. Often, the wolf dream reflected things in the real world in strange or unexpected ways.

hɑpɝ stʊɾ ɑn ði aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ. pɛɹɪn kəd fil wʊlvz ɔl əkɹɔs ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt.

Hopper stood on the outcropping. Perrin could feel wolves all across the slopes of Dragonmount.

ɪn ivən ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝz ðən hid fɛl hɪɹ ɹisənli.

In even greater numbers than he'd felt here recently.

ðeɪ weɪt, hɑpɝ sɛd. ðə læs hʌn kʌmz.

They wait, Hopper said. The Last Hunt comes.

əz pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt aʊt, hi faʊn ðəɾ ʌðɝ pæks wɝ kʌmɪŋ, stɪl dɪstən bʌt muvɪŋ təwɔɹd dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌpwɝɾ ət ðə mɑnstʃɹəs pik. ðə tum ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, luz θɝɪn. ɪt wɑz ə mɑnjəmən tə hɪz mædnəs, tə boʊθ ɪz feɪljɝ ən ɪz səksɛs. hɪz pɹaɪɾ ən ɪz sɛlf-sækɹəfaɪs.

As Perrin reached out, he found that other packs were coming, still distant but moving toward Dragonmount. Perrin looked upward at the monstrous peak. The tomb of the Dragon, Lews Therin. It was a monument to his madness, to both his failure and his success. His pride and his self-sacrifice.

"ðə wʊlvz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ ɡæðɝ fəɹ ðə læs hʌnt?"

"The wolves," Perrin said. "They gather for the Last Hunt?"

jɛs. ɪf ɪɾ əkɝz.

Yes. If it occurs.

pɛɹɪn tɝn bæk tə hɑpɝ. "ju sɛd ðəɾ ɪt wʊd. 'ðə læs hʌn kʌmz,' jə sɛd."

Perrin turned back to Hopper. "You said that it would. 'The Last Hunt comes,' you said."

ə tʃɔɪs mʌs bi meɪd, jʌŋ bʊl. wʌn pæθ lidz tə ðə læs hʌnt.

A choice must be made, Young Bull. One path leads to the Last Hunt.

"æn ði ʌðɝ?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"And the other?" Perrin asked.

hɑpɝ dɪdn ɹɪspɑn ɪmiɾiətli. hi tɝn təwɔɹd dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ði ʌðɝ pæθ dʌz nɑt lɛd tə ðə læs hʌnt.

Hopper didn't respond immediately. He turned toward Dragonmount. The other path does not lead to the Last Hunt.

"jɛs, bʌt wʌt dʌz ɪt lɛd tə?"

"Yes, but what does it lead to?"

tə nʌθɪŋ.

To nothing.

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə pɹɛs fɝðɝ, bʌt ðən ðə weɪɾ ə hɑpɝz sɛndɪŋ hɪt hɪm.

Perrin opened his mouth to press further, but then the weight of Hopper's sending hit him.

"nʌθɪŋ" tə ðə wʊlf mɛn ə veɪkən dɛn, ɔl ə ðə pʌps teɪkən baɪ tʃɹæpɝz. ə naɪt skaɪ ɛmpti ʌv stɑɹz.

"Nothing" to the wolf meant a vacant den, all of the pups taken by trappers. A night sky empty of stars.

ðə mun feɪɾɪŋ. ðə smɛl ʌv oʊl blʌd, dʒɹaɪ, steɪl ən fleɪkt əweɪ.

The moon fading. The smell of old blood, dry, stale and flaked away.

pɛɹɪn kloʊzd ɪz maʊð. ðə skaɪ kəntɪnjud tə tʃɝn wɪð ðət blæk stɔɹm. hi smɛld ɪɾ ɑn ðə wɪnd, ðə smɛl ə bɹoʊkən tʃɹiz ən dɝt, əɹ flʌɾəd filz ən laɪtnɪŋ faɪɝz. əz soʊ ɔfən, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɹisənli, ðoʊz sɛns sim tə kəntʃɹæst wɪð ðə wɝld ɝaʊn hɪm. wʌn ə hɪz sɛnsɪz toʊld ɪm i wɑz ɪn ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ʌv ə kətæstʃɹəfi waɪl ði ʌðɝz sɔ nʌθɪŋ əmɪs.

Perrin closed his mouth. The sky continued to churn with that black storm. He smelled it on the wind, the smell of broken trees and dirt, or flooded fields and lightning fires. As so often, particularly recently, those scents seemed to contrast with the world around him. One of his senses told him he was in the very center of a catastrophe while the others saw nothing amiss.

"ðɪs tʃɔɪs. waɪ doʊnt wi dʒʌs meɪk ɪt?"

"This choice. Why don't we just make it?"

ɪts nɑɾ əɹ tʃoʊk, jʌŋ bʊl.

It is not our choke, Young Bull.

pɛɹɪn fɛl dʒɹɔn tə ðə klaʊdz əbʌv. dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, hi bɪɡæn tə wɔk ʌp ðə sloʊp. hɑpɝ loʊpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪts deɪnʒɝəs əbʌv, jʌŋ bʊl.

Perrin felt drawn to the clouds above. Despite himself, he began to walk up the slope. Hopper loped up beside him. It is dangerous above, Young Bull.

"aɪ noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. bʌɾ i kʊdn stɑp. ɪnstɛd, hi ɪnkɹist ɪz spid, itʃ stɛp lɔntʃɪŋ ɪm dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl fɑɹðɝ. hɑpɝ ɹæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm pæsɪŋ tʃɹiz, ɹɑks, ɡɹups ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ wʊlvz.

"I know," Perrin said. But he couldn't stop. Instead, he increased his speed, each step launching him just a little farther. Hopper ran beside him passing trees, rocks, groups of watching wolves.

ʌpwɝd pɛɹɪn ən hɑpɝ wɛnt, klaɪmɪŋ əntɪl ðə tʃɹiz dwɪndəld ən ðə ɡɹaʊnd ɡɹu koʊld wɪð fɹɔst ən aɪs.

Upward Perrin and Hopper went, climbing until the trees dwindled and the ground grew cold with frost and ice.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə klaʊɾ ɪtsɛlf. ɪt simd ə dɑɹk fɑɡ, ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪð kɝəns əz ɪt spʌn. pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ət ðə pɝɪməɾɝ, ðən stɛpt ɪnsaɪd. ɪt wɑz laɪk stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə naɪtmɛɹ.

Eventually, they approached the cloud itself. It seemed a dark fog, shaking with currents as it spun. Perrin hesitated at the perimeter, then stepped inside. It was like stepping into the nightmare.

ðə wɪnd wɑz sʌɾənli vaɪələnt, ði ɛɹ bʌzɪŋ wɪð ɛnɝdʒi. livz ən dɝɾ ən ɡɹɪt blu ɪn ðə tɛmpəst, ən i hæd tə ɹeɪz ə hæn əɡɛnst ɪt.

The wind was suddenly violent, the air buzzing with energy. Leaves and dirt and grit blew in the tempest, and he had to raise a hand against it.

noʊ, hi θɔt.

No, he thought.

ə smɔl bʌbəl ə kɑm ɛɹ oʊpən ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə tɛmpəs kəntɪnjud tə bloʊ dʒʌst ɪntʃəz fɹəm ɪz feɪs, ən i hæd tə stʃɹeɪn tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ kleɪm baɪ ɪɾ əɡɛn. ðɪs stɔɹm wɑzn ə naɪtmɛɹ əɹ ə dʒɹim; ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ væst, sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɹil. ðɪs taɪm, pɛɹɪn wɑz ðə wʌn kɹieɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ æbnɔɹməl wɪð ðə bʌbəl ə seɪfti.

A small bubble of calm air opened around him. The tempest continued to blow just inches from his face, and he had to strain to keep from being claimed by it again. This storm wasn't a nightmare or a dream; it was something more vast, something more real. This time, Perrin was the one creating something abnormal with the bubble of safety.

hi pɹɛs fɔɹwɝd, sun livɪŋ tʃɹæks ɪn snoʊ. hɑpɝ stʃɹoʊɾ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd, lɛsənɪŋ ɪts ɪfɛkt ɑn ɪm əz wɛl. hi wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ əɾ ɪt ðən pɛɹɪn wɑz - pɛɹɪn bɛɹli mænədʒ tə kip ɪz oʊn bʌbəl ʌp. hi fɪɹd ðət wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, hi wəd bi sʌkt ɪndə ðə stɔɹm ən tɔst ɪndə ði ɛɹ. hi sɔ lɑɹdʒ bɹæntʃəz ɹɪp pæst ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ivən səm smɔlɝ tʃɹiz.

He pressed forward, soon leaving tracks in snow. Hopper strode against the wind, lessening its effect on him as well. He was stronger at it than Perrin was - Perrin barely managed to keep his own bubble up. He feared that without it, he would be sucked into the storm and tossed into the air. He saw large branches rip past in the air, and even some smaller trees.

hɑpɝ sloʊd, ðən sæt daʊn ɪn ðə snoʊ. hi lʊkt ʌpwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə pik. aɪ kænɑt steɪ, ðə wʊlf sɛnt. ðɪs ɪz nɑt maɪ pleɪs.

Hopper slowed, then sat down in the snow. He looked upward, toward the peak. I cannot stay, the wolf sent. This is not my place.

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I understand," Perrin said.

ðə wʊlf vænɪʃt, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud. hi kʊdn ɪkspleɪn wʌt dʒɹu hɪm, bʌɾ i nu ðəɾ i niɾəd tə wɪtnəs. sʌmwʌn dɪd. hi wɔk fəɹ wʌt sim laɪk aʊɝz, foʊkəs kəmplitli ɑn oʊnli tu θɪŋz: kipɪŋ ðə wɪnz ɔf ɪm ən pʊɾɪŋ wʌn fʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝ.

The wolf vanished, but Perrin continued. He couldn't explain what drew him, but he knew that he needed to witness. Someone did. He walked for what seemed like hours, focused completely on only two things: keeping the winds off him and putting one foot in front of the other.

ðə stɔɹm ɡɹu ɪnkɹisɪŋli vaɪələnt. ɪt wɑz soʊ bæd hɪɹ ðəɾ i kʊdn kip ɔl ə ðə stɔɹm ɔf, dʒʌs ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt. hi pæs ðə ɹɪdʒ lɪp wɛɹ ðə maʊntəntɑp wɑz bɹoʊkən, pɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪt, hʌn- kɛɹɾ əɡɛns ðə ɡʌsts, ə stip fɔl ɑn iðɝ saɪd. wɪn bɪɡæn tə wɪp əɾ ɪz kloʊðɪŋ, ən i hæd tə skwɪn ɪz aɪz əɡɛns ðə dʌst ən snoʊ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

The storm grew increasingly violent. It was so bad here that he couldn't keep all of the storm off, just the worst of it. He passed the ridged lip where the mountaintop was broken, picking his way alongside it, hun- kered against the gusts, a steep fall on either side. Wind began to whip at his clothing, and he had to squint his eyes against the dust and snow in the air.

bʌɾ i kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn. stʃɹaɪvɪŋ fəɹ ðə pik, wɪtʃ ɹoʊz əhɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv ðə blæstəɾ aʊt saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntən. hi nu ðəɾ ətɑp ðət pɔɪn i wəd faɪnd wʌɾ i sɝtʃt fɔɹ. ðɪs hɔɹəbəl meɪlstʃɹəm wɑz ðə wʊlf dʒɹimz ɹiækʃən tə sʌmθɪŋ ɡɹeɪt, sʌmθɪŋ tɛɹəbəl. ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, səmtaɪmz θɪŋz wɝ mɔɹ ɹil ðən ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld. ðə dʒɹim ɹəflɛktəɾ ə tɛmpəs kəz sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɑz hæpənɪŋ i wɝid ðəɾ ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tɛɹəbəl.
