But he continued on. Striving for the peak, which rose ahead, rising above the blasted out side of the mountain. He knew that atop that point he would find what he searched for. This horrible maelstrom was the wolf dream's reaction to something great, something terrible. In this place, sometimes things were more real than in the waking world. The dream reflected a tempest because something very important was happening He worried that it was something terrible.

pɛɹɪn pɹɛs fɔɹwɝd, ʃʌvɪŋ ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə snoʊz, kɹɔlɪŋ ʌp ɹɑk feɪsəz, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz livɪŋ skɪn stɪkɪŋ tə ðə fɹɪdʒəd stoʊnz. bʌɾ i hæd tʃɹeɪnd wɛl ðiz læs fju wiks. hi lɛp tʃæzəmz i ʃʊdn əv bɪn eɪbəl tə lip ən klaɪmd ɹɑks ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn tu haɪ fəɹ hɪm.

Perrin pressed forward, shoving his way through the snows, crawling up rock faces, his fingers leaving skin sticking to the frigid stones. But he had trained well these last few weeks. He leapt chasms he shouldn't have been able to leap and climbed rocks that should have been too high for him.

ə fɪɡjɝ stʊɾ ət ðə vɛɹi tɑp ə ðə dʒæɡd, bɹoʊkən tɪp ə ðə maʊntən. pɛɹɪn kɛpt pɹɛsɪŋ ɔnwɝd. sʌmwʌn niɾəd tə wɑtʃ. sʌmwʌn niɾəd tə bi ðəɹ wən ɪt hæpənd.

A figure stood at the very top of the jagged, broken tip of the mountain. Perrin kept pressing onward. Someone needed to watch. Someone needed to be there when it happened.

faɪnəli, pɛɹɪn hivd ətɑp wʌn læst stoʊn ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɪðɪn ə dʌzən fiɾ ə ðə tɑp. hi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə fɪɡjɝ naʊ. ðə mæn stʊɾ ət ðə vɛɹi hɑɹɾ ə ðə vɔɹɾɛks ʌv wɪnz, stɛɹɪŋ istwɝd, moʊʃənləs. hi wɑz feɪn ən tʃɹænslusənt, ə ɹəflɛkʃən ə ðə ɹil wɝld. laɪk ə ʃædoʊ.

Finally, Perrin heaved atop one last stone and found himself within a dozen feet of the top. He could make out the figure now. The man stood at the very heart of the vortex of winds, staring eastward, motionless. He was faint and translucent, a reflection of the real world. Like a shadow.

pɛɹɪn hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɪt.

Perrin had never seen anything like it.

ɪt wɑz ɹænd, ʌv kɔɹs. pɛɹɪn hæd noʊn ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi. pɛɹɪn hɛl tə ðə stoʊn wɪð wʌn ɹæɡəd hæn ən pʊld ɪz kloʊk kloʊs wɪð ði ʌðɝ - hid kɹieɪɾəd ðə kloʊk sɛvɹəl klɪf feɪsəz əɡoʊ.

It was Rand, of course. Perrin had known that it would be. Perrin held to the stone with one ragged hand and pulled his cloak close with the other - he'd created the cloak several cliff faces ago.

hi blɪŋk θɹu ɹɛɾənd aɪz, ɡeɪzɪŋ ʌpwɝd. hi hæd tə foʊkəs moʊst ə hɪz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən ɑn pʊʃɪŋ bæk səm ə ðə wɪnz tə kip hɪmsɛlf fɹəm biɪŋ flʌŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə tɛmpəst.

He blinked through reddened eyes, gazing upward. He had to focus most of his concentration on pushing back some of the winds to keep himself from being flung out into the tempest.

laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt sʌɾənli, θʌndɝ saʊndɪŋ fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns hid bɪɡʌn klaɪmɪŋ. ðət laɪtnɪŋ bɪɡæn tə ɑɹk ɪn ə doʊm ɝaʊn ðə tɑp ə ðə maʊntən. ɪt θɹu laɪɾ əkɹɔs ɹændz feɪs. ðət hɑɹd, ɪmpæsɪv feɪs, laɪk stoʊn ɪtsɛlf. wɛɹ hæɾ ɪts kɝvz ɡɔn? wən hæd ɹænd ɡeɪn soʊ mɛni laɪnz ən æŋɡəlz? ən ðoʊz aɪz, ðeɪ simd meɪɾ ə mɑɹbəl!

Lightning flashed suddenly, thunder sounding for the first time since he'd begun climbing. That lightning began to arc in a dome around the top of the mountain. It threw light across Rand's face. That hard, impassive face, like stone itself. Where had its curves gone? When had Rand gained so many lines and angles? And those eyes, they seemed made of marble!

ɹænd wɔɹ ə koʊɾ ə blæk ən ɹɛd. faɪn ən ɔɹnəmɛntɪd, wɪð ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst. ðə wɪnz dɪdn əfɛkt ɹændz kloʊðz. ðoʊz fɛl ənnətʃɝəli stɪl, əz ɪf i ɹɪli wɝ dʒʌst ə stætʃu. kɑɹv fɹəm stoʊn. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət muvd wɑz ɪz dɑɹk ɹɛd hɛɹ, bloʊɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, θɹoʊn ən spʌn.

Rand wore a coat of black and red. Fine and ornamented, with a sword at his waist. The winds didn't affect Rand's clothes. Those fell unnaturally still, as if he really were just a statue. Carved from stone. The only thing that moved was his dark red hair, blowing in the wind, thrown and spun.

pɛɹɪn klʌŋ tə ðə ɹɑks fəɹ ɪz laɪf, koʊld wɪn baɪɾɪŋ ɪndə hɪz tʃiks, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən fit soʊ nʌm i kəd bɛɹli fil ðɛm. hɪz bɪɹd bɹɪsəld wɪð dʌsti aɪs ən snoʊ. sʌmθɪŋ blæk bɪɡæn tə spɪn ɝaʊn ɹænd. ɪt wɑzn pɑɹɾ ə ðə stɔɹm; ɪt sim laɪk naɪɾ ɪtsɛlf likɪŋ fɹəm hɪm. tɛnʒɹəlz ʌv ɪt ɡɹu fɹəm ɹændz oʊn skɪn, laɪk taɪni hænz kɝlɪŋ bæk ən ɹæpɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ɪt simd ivəl ɪtsɛlf ɡɪvən laɪf.

Perrin clung to the rocks for his life, cold wind biting into his cheeks, his fingers and feet so numb he could barely feel them. His beard bristled with dusty ice and snow. Something black began to spin around Rand. It wasn't part of the storm; it seemed like night itself leaking from him. Tendrils of it grew from Rand's own skin, like tiny hands curling back and wrapping around him. It seemed evil itself given life.

"ɹænd!" pɛɹɪn bɛloʊd. "faɪɾ ɪt! ɹænd!"

"Rand!" Perrin bellowed. "Fight it! Rand!"

hɪz vɔɪs wɑz lɔst ɪn ðə wɪnd, ən i daʊɾɪd ðət ɹænd cʊɾə hɝɾ ɪm ɛniweɪ. ðə dɑɹknəs kəntɪnjud tə sip aʊt, laɪk ə lɪkwəd tɑɹ kʌmɪŋ θɹu ɹændz pɔɹz, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə miæzmə ʌv pɪtʃ ɝaʊn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. wɪðɪn moʊməns, pɛɹɪn kəd bɛɹli si ɹænd θɹu ðə blæknəs. ɪɾ ɛnkloʊz hɪm, kʌɾɪŋ ɪm ɔf, bænɪʃɪŋ hɪm. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ɡɔn. oʊnli ivəl ɹɪmeɪnd.

His voice was lost in the wind, and he doubted that Rand could have heard him anyway. The darkness continued to seep out, like a liquid tar coming through Rand's pores, creating a miasma of pitch around the Dragon Reborn. Within moments, Perrin could barely see Rand through the blackness. It enclosed him, cutting him off, banishing him. The Dragon Reborn was gone. Only evil remained.

"ɹænd, pliz . . ." pɛɹɪn wɪspɝd.

"Rand, please . . ." Perrin whispered.

ən ðən - fɹəm ðə mɪdst ə ðə blæknəs, fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ə ði ʌpɹɔɹ ən ðə tɛmpəst - ə taɪni slɪvɝ ə laɪt splɪt θɹu ði ivəl. laɪk ə kændəlz ɡloʊ ɑn ə vɛɹi dɑɹk naɪt. ðə laɪt ʃoʊn ʌpwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə dɪstən skaɪ, laɪk ə bikən. soʊ fɹeɪl.

And then - from the midst of the blackness, from the center of the uproar and the tempest - a tiny sliver of light split through the evil. Like a candle's glow on a very dark night. The light shone upward, toward the distant sky, like a beacon. So frail.

ðə tɛmpəs bəfeɪɾ ɪt. ðə wɪnz stɔɹmd, haʊld, ən skɹimd. ðə laɪtnɪŋ biɾ əɡɛns ðə tɑp ə ðə ɹɑki pik, blæstɪŋ fɹi tʃʌŋks ə ɹɑk, skɔɹɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə blæknəs ənʒəleɪtɪd ən pʌlsd.

The tempest buffeted it. The winds stormed, howled, and screamed. The lightning beat against the top of the rocky peak, blasting free chunks of rock, scoring the ground. The blackness undulated and pulsed.

bʌt stɪl ðə laɪt ʃoʊn.

But still the light shone.

ə wɛb ə kɹæks əpɪɹd daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ʃɛl ʌv ivəl blæknəs, laɪt ʃaɪnɪŋ fɹəm wɪðɪn.

A web of cracks appeared down the side of the shell of evil blackness, light shining from within.

ənʌðɝ fɹæktʃɝ dʒɔɪn ɪt, ən ənʌðɝ. sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ wɑz ɪnsaɪd, sʌmθɪŋ ɡloʊɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ bɹɪljənt.

Another fracture joined it, and another. Something strong was inside, something glowing, something brilliant.

ðə ʃɛl ɪksploʊɾəd aʊtwɝd, veɪpɝaɪzɪŋ ən ɹilisɪŋ ə kɑləm ə laɪt soʊ bɹaɪt, soʊ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ðəɾ ɪt sim tə sɪɹ ði aɪz fɹəm pɛɹɪnz hɛd. bʌɾ i lʊkt ɑn ɛniweɪ, nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ ɑɹm tə ʃeɪɾ əɹ blɑk ðə ɹisplɛndən ɪmədʒ bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ɹænd stʊd wɪðɪn ðət laɪt, maʊθ oʊpən əz ɪf bɛloʊɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə skaɪz əbʌv. ðə sʌn-jɛloʊd kɑləm ʃɑɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ən ðə stɔɹm sim tə ʃʌɾɝ, ði ɪntaɪɝ skaɪ ɪtsɛlf ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ.

The shell exploded outward, vaporizing and releasing a column of light so bright, so incredible that it seemed to sear the eyes from Perrin's head. But he looked on anyway, not raising arm to shade or block the resplendent image before him. Rand stood within that light, mouth open as if bellowing toward the skies above. The sun-yellowed column shot into the air, and the storm seemed to shudder, the entire sky itself undulating.

ðə tɛmpəs vænɪʃt.

The tempest vanished.

ðət kɑləm ə faɪɝi laɪt bɪkeɪm ə kɑləm ə sʌnlaɪt stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ðə pik ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. pɛɹɪn pʊld ɪz fɪŋɡɝz fɹi fɹəm ðə ɹɑk, ɡeɪzɪŋ ɑn wɪð wʌndɝ ət ɹænd stændɪŋ wɪðɪn ðə laɪt. ɪt sim soʊ lɔŋ, soʊ vɛɹi lɔŋ, sɪns pɛɹɪn hæd sin ə ɹeɪ ʌv pjʊɹ sʌnlaɪt.

That column of fiery light became a column of sunlight streaming down, illuminating the peak of Dragonmount. Perrin pulled his fingers free from the rock, gazing on with wonder at Rand standing within the light. It seemed so long, so very long, since Perrin had seen a ray of pure sunlight.

ðə wʊlvz bɪɡæn tə haʊl. ɪt wɑz ə haʊl ə tʃɹaɪəmf, ʌv ɡlɔɹi ən ə vɪktɝi. pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛɾ ən haʊld əz wɛl, bɪkʌmɪŋ jʌŋ bʊl fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hi kəd fil ðə pul ə sʌnlaɪt ɡɹoʊɪŋ, ən ɪt wɑʃt oʊvɝ hɪm, ɪts wɔɹmθ bænɪʃɪŋ ðə fɹoʊzən tʃɪl. hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst wən ɹændz ɪmədʒ vænɪʃt, fəɹ i lɛf ðət sʌnlaɪt bɪhaɪnd.

The wolves began to howl. It was a howl of triumph, of glory and of victory. Perrin raised his head and howled as well, becoming Young Bull for a moment. He could feel the pool of sunlight growing, and it washed over him, its warmth banishing the frozen chill. He barely noticed when Rand's image vanished, for he left that sunlight behind.

wʊlvz əpɪɹɾ ɝaʊn pɛɹɪn, flæʃɪŋ ɪndə ɛɡzɪstəns mɪdlip. ðeɪ kəntɪnjud tə beɪ, dʒʌmpɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ɪɡzʌltɪŋ ən dænsɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪɾ əz ɪt wɑʃt oʊvɝ ðɛm. ðeɪ jɪpt ən bɑɹkt, tɔsɪŋ ʌp pætʃəz ə snoʊ əz ðeɪ baʊndəd. hɑpɝ wɑz əmʌŋ ðɛm, ən i lɛpt ɪndə ði ɛɹ, sɔɹɪŋ oʊvɝ tə pɛɹɪn. ðə læs hʌn bɪɡɪnz, jʌŋ bʊl! hɑpɝ skɹimd. wi laɪv. wi lɪv!

Wolves appeared around Perrin, flashing into existence midleap. They continued to bay, jumping at one another, exulting and dancing in the Wight as it washed over them. They yipped and barked, tossing up patches of snow as they bounded. Hopper was among them, and he leaped into the air, soaring over to Perrin. The Last Hunt begins, Young Bull! Hopper screamed. We live. We live!

pɛɹɪn tɝn bæk tə ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ɹænd hæd stʊd. ɪf ðət dɑɹkn hæd teɪkən ɹænd ... bʌɾ ɪt hædnt. hi smaɪl bɹɔdli. "ðə læs hʌn əz kʌm'" hi skɹim tə ðə wʊlvz. "lɛɾ ɪt bɪɡɪn!"

Perrin turned back to the place where Rand had stood. If that darkn had taken Rand ... But it hadn't. He smiled broadly. "The Last Hunt has come'" he screamed to the wolves. "Let it begin!"

ðeɪ haʊl ðɛɹ əɡɹimənt, əz laʊɾ əz ðə stɔɹm hæd bɪn dʒʌs moʊ-mɛns bɪfɔɹ.

They howled their agreement, as loud as the storm had been just mo-ments before.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 31

ɪndə ðə vɔɪd


Into the Void

mæt dʌmp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə waɪn ɪndə hɪz maʊθ, seɪvɝɪŋ ðə swit, kul teɪst. hi bɹɔt ðə kʌp daʊn ən tɔst ə hændfʊl ə faɪv daɪs. ðeɪ tʌmbəl tə ðə wʊɾən flɔɹ ə ðə tævɝn, klækɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Mat dumped the rest of the wine into his mouth, savoring the sweet, cool taste. He brought the cup down and tossed a handful of five dice. They tumbled to the wooden floor of the tavern, clacking against one another.

ði ɛɹ wɑz θɪk. θɪk wɪð saʊnz, θɪk wɪð kɝsɪz, θɪk wɪð sɛns. smoʊk, pʌnʒənt lɪkɝz, ə steɪk ðət hæd bɪn pɛpɝd soʊ mʌtʃ ðət jə kəd hɑɹdli teɪs ðə mit. ðət wɑz pɹɑbli fəɹ ðə bɛst. ivən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, mit spɔɪld ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbli.

The air was thick. Thick with sounds, thick with curses, thick with scents. Smoke, pungent liquors, a steak that had been peppered so much that you could hardly taste the meat. That was probably for the best. Even in Caemlyn, meat spoiled unpredictably.

ðə pʌnʒənt mɛn ɝaʊn mæt wɑtʃt ɪz daɪs fɔl: wʌn ə ðə mɛn stæŋk ʌv ɡɑɹlɪk, ənʌðɝ ə swɛt, ə θɝɾ ʌv ə tænɝi. ðɛɹ hɛɹ wɑz stʃɹɪŋi, ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz wɝ ɡɹaɪmi, bʌt ðɛɹ kɔɪn wɑz ɡʊd.

The pungent men around Mat watched his dice fall: one of the men stank of garlic, another of sweat, a third of a tannery. Their hair was stringy, their fingers were grimy, but their coin was good.

ðə ɡeɪm wɑz kɔl kɔɝɑŋkoʊz spɪt, ən heɪl fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ.

The game was called Koronko's Spit, and hailed from Shienar.

mæt dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə ɹulz.

Mat did not know the rules.

'faɪv wʌnz," sɛd ðə mæn u stæŋk ʌv ɡɑɹlɪk. hɪz neɪm wɑz ɹɪɾəl. hi simd ənsɛɾəld. "ðæts ə lɔs."

'Five ones," said the man who stank of garlic. His name was Rittle. He seemed unsettled. "That's a loss."

"noʊ ɪts nɑt," mæt sɛd sɔfli. nɛvɝ maɪn ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə ɹulz. hi nu hi hæd wʌn; hi kəd fil ɪt. hɪz lʌk wɑz wɪð hɪm.

"No it's not," Mat said softly. Never mind that he did not know the rules. He knew he had won; he could feel it. His luck was with him.

ɡʊd θɪŋ, tu. hi niɾəd ɪt tənaɪt.

Good thing, too. He needed it tonight.

ðə mæn ðət smɛld ʌv ə tænɝi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz bɛlt, wɛɹ i kæɹiɾ ə wɪkəd naɪf. hɪz neɪm wɑz sæɾəlɝ, ən i hæɾ ə tʃɪn ðət cʊɾə bɪn juz tə ʃɑɹpən sɔɹdz. "aɪ θɔt jə sɛd jə dɪdnt noʊ ðɪs ɡeɪm, fɹɛnd."

The man that smelled of a tannery reached for his belt, where he carried a wicked knife. His name was Saddler, and he had a chin that could have been used to sharpen swords. "I thought you said you didn't know this game, friend."

"aɪ doʊnt," mæt sɛd. "fɹɛnd. bʌt ðæts ə wɪn. də wi nid tə æsk ɝaʊn ðə ɹum tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls kən kənfɝm ɪt?"

"I don't," Mat said. "Friend. But that's a win. Do we need to ask around the room to see if anyone else can confirm it?"

ðə θɹi mɛn lʊkt əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, ɪkspɹɛʃənz dɑɹk. mæt stʊɾ ʌp. ði ɪn hæd wɔlz dɑɹk fɹəm jɪɹz ə mɛn smoʊkɪŋ paɪps ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt, ən ðə wɪndoʊz - ðoʊ ʌv faɪn ɡlæs - hæd ɡɹoʊn oʊpeɪk wɪð dɝɾ ən smoʊk. ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹədɪʃən ðət ðeɪ nɛvɝ bi klind. ðə wɛðɝd saɪn aʊt fɹʌn hæɾ ə wæɡən wil peɪntəɾ ɑn ɪt, ən ði əfɪʃəl neɪm wɑz ðə dʌsti wil. ɛvɹiwʌn kɔld ɪt ðə ɹumɝ wil ɪnstɛd; ɪt wɑz ðə bɛs pleɪs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn tə lɪsən tə ɹumɝz. moʊst ə ðɛm wɝ əntʃɹu, bʌt ðət wɑz hæf ðə fʌn.

The three men looked at each other, expressions dark. Mat stood up. The inn had walls dark from years of men smoking pipes inside it, and the windows - though of fine glass - had grown opaque with dirt and smoke. It was a tradition that they never be cleaned. The weathered sign out front had a wagon wheel painted on it, and the official name was The Dusty Wheel. Everyone called it The Rumor Wheel instead; it was the best place in Caemlyn to listen to rumors. Most of them were untrue, but that was half the fun.

moʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə pleɪs wɑz dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ eɪl, bʌt mæt hæd teɪkən ə fænsi tə ɡʊd ɹɛd waɪn leɪtli.

Most everyone in the place was drinking ale, but Mat had taken a fancy to good red wine lately.

"wɑn səm mɔɹ, mæstɝ kɹɪmzən?" kɑɾi, ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən, æskt. ʃi wɑz ə ɹeɪvən-hɛɹd bjuɾi wɪð ə smaɪl soʊ waɪɾ ɪt ɹitʃt hæfweɪ tə kɛɹhin. ʃi hæd bɪn flɝɾɪŋ wɪð ɪm ɔl naɪt. nɛvɝ maɪn ðəɾ i hæd toʊld əɹ i wɑz mɛɹid. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən smaɪld ət hɝ. wɛl, nɑt mʌtʃ. ən hɑɹdli hɪz bɛst smaɪl. səm wɪmən kəd nɑt si ðə tʃɹuθ ə θɪŋz, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz ɹɪɾən ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn fɔɹhɛdz, ðət wɑz ə fækt.

"Want some more, Master Crimson?" Kati, the serving woman, asked. She was a raven-haired beauty with a smile so wide it reached halfway to Cairhien. She had been flirting with him all night. Never mind that he had told her he was married. He had not even smiled at her. Well, not much. And hardly his best smile. Some women could not see the truth of things, even if it was written on their own foreheads, that was a fact.

hi weɪvd əɹ əweɪ. oʊnli wʌn kʌp tənaɪt, fəɹ kɝədʒ. bɝn hɪm, bʌɾ i niɾəd ə lɪɾəl ə ðæt.

He waved her away. Only one cup tonight, for courage. Burn him, but he needed a little of that.

wɪð ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən, hi tʊk ðə skɑɹf ɔf ɪz nɛk ən dʒɹɑpt ɪt tə ðə saɪd. hi əntʌk ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən - laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɡʊd tə bi wɛɹɪŋ ðəɾ əɡɛn! - ən hʌŋ ɪɾ aʊt fɹʌn ə hɪz kloʊðɪŋ. hi wɔɹ ðə nu ɹɛɾ ən sɪlvɝ koʊt ðət θɔɹn hæd bɑt hɪm.

With resignation, he took the scarf off his neck and dropped it to the side. He untucked the foxhead medallion - Light, but it felt good to be wearing that again! - and hung it out front of his clothing. He wore the new red and silver coat that Thorn had bought him.

mæt tʊk ɪz æsbændʒɹeɪ fɹəm bɪsaɪd ðə wɔl ən pʊld ɔf ðə klɔθ kʌvɝ, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə bleɪd.

Mat took his asbandarei from beside the wall and pulled off the cloth cover, revealing the blade.

hi sɛɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "heɪ," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə laʊd vɔɪs. "ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə blʌɾi pleɪs noʊ ðə ɹulz fəɹ kɔɝɑŋkoʊz spɪt?"

He set it over his shoulder. "Hey," he said in a loud voice. "Anyone in the bloody place know the rules for Koronko's Spit?"

ðə θɹi mɛn i hæd bɪn dɪsɪŋ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə wɛpən; ðə θɝɾ ə ðɛm, snɛl, stʊɾ ʌp, hʊkɪŋ ɪz θʌmz ɪndə ðə tɑp ə hɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz, pʊʃɪŋ bæk ɪz koʊɾ ən ʃoʊɪŋ ðə ʃɔɹtsɔɝd bʌkəld əɾ ɪz weɪst.

The three men he had been dicing regarded the weapon; the third of them, Snelle, stood up, hooking his thumbs into the top of his trousers, pushing back his coat and showing the shortsword buckled at his waist.

moʊs pipəl ɪɡnɔɹd mæt ət fɝst. kɑnvɝseɪʃənz ɹæŋ, stɔɹiz əbaʊt ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ ɑɹmi ðət hæd pæst, əbaʊt ðə kwinz pɹɛɡnənsi, əbaʊt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, əbaʊt mɪstɪɹiəs dɛθs əɹ nɑt soʊ mɪstɪɹiəs wʌnz. ɛvɹiwʌn hæɾ ə ɹumɝ tə ʃɛɹ. səm ə ði ɪnz ɑkjəpəns wɔɹ lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ðən ɹæɡz, bʌt səm wɔɹ ðə faɪnəst ə kloʊðɪŋ. noʊbəlz, kɑmənɝz ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn bɪtwin keɪm tə ðə ɹumɝ wil.

Most people ignored Mat at first. Conversations rang, stories about the Borderlander army that had passed, about the Queen's pregnancy, about the Dragon Reborn, about mysterious deaths or not so mysterious ones. Everyone had a rumor to share. Some of the inn's occupants wore little better than rags, but some wore the finest of clothing. Nobles, commoners and everything in between came to The Rumor Wheel.

ə fju mɛn baɪ ðə bɑɹ ɡlænst ət mæt kəz ə ði aʊtbɝst. wʌn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, blɪŋkɪŋ. mæt ɹitʃt daʊn ən tʊk ɪz waɪd-bɹɪm blæk hæɾ ɔf ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪd hɪm, hoʊldɪŋ ɪt baɪ ðə kɹaʊn, ðən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. ðə mæn nʌdʒd ɪz kəmpænjənz. ðə swɛɾi, bɔldɪŋ mæn mæt hæd bɪn dɪsɪŋ wɪð ɹeɪz fɪŋɡɝz tə hɪz tʃɪn, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn θɔt, əz ɪf tʃɹaɪ-ɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ sʌmθɪŋ.

A few men by the bar glanced at Mat because of the outburst. One hesitated, blinking. Mat reached down and took his wide-brimmed black hat off the table beside him, holding it by the crown, then set it on his head. The man nudged his companions. The sweaty, balding man Mat had been dicing with raised fingers to his chin, rubbing it in thought, as if try-ing to remember something.

snɛl smaɪld ət mæt. "lʊks laɪk noʊbɑdi ænsɝd ju, fɹɛnd. ɡɛs jəl əv tə tʃɹʌst ʌs. jə ʃʊdn əv θɹoʊn ɪf jə dɪdn æsk ðə ɹulz. naʊ, ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə peɪ, əɹ - "

Snelle smiled at Mat. "Looks like nobody answered you, friend. Guess you'll have to trust us. You shouldn't have thrown if you didn't ask the rules. Now, are you going to pay, or - "

ɹɪɾəlz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən i stʊd heɪstəli ən tʊk ɪz fɹɛnz ɑɹm. hi lin ɪn, wɪspɝɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. snɛl lʊk daʊn ət mæts mədæljən. hi lʊkt ʌp ən mɛt mæts aɪz.

Rittle's eyes opened wide, and he stood hastily and took his friend's arm. He leaned in, whispering something. Snelle looked down at Mat's medallion. He looked up and met Mat's eyes.

mæt nɑɾəd.

Mat nodded.

"ɪkskjus ʌs," ɹɪɾəl sɛd, stʌmbəlɪŋ əweɪ. ði ʌðɝ tu dʒɔɪn hɪm. ðeɪ lɛf ðɛɹ daɪs ən kɔɪnz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

"Excuse us," Rittle said, stumbling away. The other two joined him. They left their dice and coins on the ground.

mæt kæʒəwəli nɛl daʊn, skupɪŋ ʌp ðə kɔɪnz ən dʌmpɪŋ əm ɪn ɪz paʊtʃ. hi lɛf ðə daɪs.

Mat casually knelt down, scooping up the coins and dumping them in his pouch. He left the dice.

ðeɪ wɝ loʊɾəd, mɛn tə ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz θɹoʊ θɹiz. hi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə dʒʌdʒ ðət fɹəm ə fju kwɪk θɹoʊz bɪfɔɹ leɪɪŋ daʊn kɔɪnz.

They were loaded, meant to almost always throw threes. He had been able to judge that from a few quick throws before laying down coins.

wɪspɝz muv θɹu ði ɪnz kɑmən ɹum laɪk ə swɔɹm ʌv æns kʌvɝɪŋ ə kɔɹps. tʃɛɹz skuɾɪd bæk. kɑnvɝseɪʃənz tʃeɪnʒd tɛmpoʊ, səm saɪlənsɪŋ, ʌðɝz bɪkʌmɪŋ ɝdʒənt. mæt stʊɾ ʌp tə ɡoʊ. pipəl heɪsən aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ.

Whispers moved through the inn's common room like a swarm of ants covering a corpse. Chairs scooted back. Conversations changed tempo, some silencing, others becoming urgent. Mat stood up to go. People hastened out of his way.

mæt lɛft ə ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɑɹ, ðən tɪpt ɪz hæt tə hætʃ, ði ɪnkipɝ. ðə mæn stʊd bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹ waɪpɪŋ ə ɡlæs, hɪz waɪf nɛks tə hɪm. ʃi wɑz ə pɹɪɾi wʌn, bʌt hætʃ kɛpt ə spɛʃəl kʌdʒəl fəɹ θʌmpɪŋ mɛn u lʊk tu lɔŋ. mæt ɡeɪv əɹ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt lʊk, ðɛn.

Mat left a golden crown on the edge of the bar, then tipped his hat to Hatch, the innkeeper. The man stood behind the bar wiping a glass, his wife next to him. She was a pretty one, but Hatch kept a special cudgel for thumping men who looked too long. Mat gave her only a short look, then.

mæt pʊld ɔf ɪz blæk skɑɹf, livɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɪt hæɾ ə hoʊl ɪn ɪt naʊ ɛniweɪ. hi stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt, ən ðə moʊmən i dɪd, ðə daɪs stɑp θʌndɝɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd.

Mat pulled off his black scarf, leaving it on the floor. It had a hole in it now anyway. He stepped out into the night, and the moment he did, the dice stopped thundering in his head.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɡɛt tə wɝk.

It was time to get to work.

hi wɔkt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹit. hi hæd spɛn ɔl ivnɪŋ wɪð ɪz feɪs ənkʌvɝd. hi wɑz sɝɾən i hæd bɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ə fju taɪmz, moʊsli baɪ mɛn u hæd slɪpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. əz i wɔk daʊn ɔf ði ɪnz fɹʌn pɔɹtʃ, pipəl ɡæðɝɾ ət ðə wɪndoʊz ən dɔɹweɪ.

He walked out onto the street. He had spent all evening with his face uncovered. He was certain he had been recognized a few times, mostly by men who had slipped out into the night without saying anything. As he walked down off the inn's front porch, people gathered at the windows and doorway.

mæt tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə fil laɪk ɔl ə ðoʊz aɪz wɝ naɪvz stɪkɪŋ ɪndə hɪz bæk. laɪt, hi fɛlt laɪk i wɑz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ənʌðɝ nus. hi ɹitʃt ʌp ən fɛlt ət ðə skɑɹ ɑn ɪz nɛk. ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl sɪns i hæd ɡɔn əbaʊt wɪð ɪz nɛk ənkʌvɝd. ivən wɪð taɪlɪn, hi hæd nɔɹməli lɛf ðə skɑɹf ɑn.

Mat tried not to feel like all of those eyes were knives sticking into his back. Light, he felt like he was dangling from another noose. He reached up and felt at the scar on his neck. It had been a long while since he had gone about with his neck uncovered. Even with Tylin, he had normally left the scarf on.

tənaɪt, ðoʊ, hi dænst wɪð dʒæk oʊ' ðə ʃædoʊz. hi taɪɾ ɪz mədæljən tə ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ. hi əfɪkst ɪt soʊ ðət ðə mədæljən ɹɛstəɾ əɡɛns ðə flæɾ ə ðə bleɪd, ən wʌn ɛdʒ hʌŋ aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə tɪp. ɪt wəd bi hɑɹd tə juz - hi wəɾ əv tə hɪt wɪð ðə flæɾ ə ðə bleɪɾ ɪn moʊs keɪsəz tə tʌtʃ ðə mədæljən tə flɛʃ; - bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ɹitʃ ðən swɪŋɪŋ ðə mədæljən baɪ hænd.

Tonight, though, he danced with Jak o' the Shadows. He tied his medallion to the ashandarei. He affixed it so that the medallion rested against the flat of the blade, and one edge hung out over the tip. It would be hard to use - he would have to hit with the flat of the blade in most cases to touch the medallion to flesh; - but it gave him much better reach than swinging the medallion by hand.

mədæljən ɪn pleɪs, hi pɪkt ə dɝɛkʃən ən bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ. hi wɑz ɪn ðə nu sɪɾi, ə pleɪs hipt wɪð mæn-meɪd bɪldɪŋz, ə kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə faɪn oʊɡiɝ wɝk ɛlswɛɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðiz bɪldɪŋz wɝ wɛl bɪlt, bʌt wɝ nɛɹoʊ ən θɪn, ʌp kloʊs nɛks tə wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Medallion in place, he picked a direction and began walking. He was in the New City, a place heaped with man-made buildings, a contrast to the fine Ogier work elsewhere in Caemlyn. These buildings were well built, but were narrow and thin, up close next to one another.

ðə fɝst ɡɹup tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪm bɪfɔɹ i wɑz wʌn stʃɹiɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹumɝ wil. ðəɹ wɝ fɔɹ ə ðɛm. əz ðeɪ tʃɑɹdʒ hɪm, ə ɡɹup ə ʃædoʊz lɛp fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ æliweɪ, tælmɑnz ət ðɛɹ hɛd. mæt spʌn ɑn ðə kɪlɝz, hu pʊld ʌp ʃɔɹɾ əz ɪz soʊlʒɝz dʒɔɪn hɪm. ðə stʃɹit tʌfs flɛɾ ɪn ə skɹæmbəl ən mæt nɑɾəd tə tælmɑnz.

The first group tried to kill him before he was one street away from The Rumor Wheel. There were four of them. As they charged him, a group of shadows leaped from a nearby alleyway, Talmanes at their head. Mat spun on the killers, who pulled up short as his soldiers joined him. The street toughs fled in a scramble and Mat nodded to Talmanes.

ðə mɛn ə ðə bæn feɪɾəd bæk ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs, ən mæt kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn ɪz weɪ. hi wɔk sloʊli, kæɹiɪŋ ɪz æsbændʒɹeɪ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz mɛn hæd bɪn toʊl tə kip ðɛɹ dɪstəns ənlɛs i wɑz ətækt.

The men of the Band faded back into the darkness, and Mat continued on his way. He walked slowly, carrying his asbandarei on his shoulder. His men had been told to keep their distance unless he was attacked.

hi ɛndəɾ ʌp niɾɪŋ əm θɹi mɔɹ taɪmz θɹu ði aʊɝ, itʃ taɪm skɛɹɪŋ əweɪ ə lɑɹdʒɝ ɡɹup ə θʌɡz. ðə læs taɪm, ðə bæn ən i æktʃəli  klæʃt wɪð ði əsæsənz. ðə θʌɡz wɝ noʊ mætʃ fəɹ tʃɹeɪn soʊlʒɝz, ivən ɑn ðə dɑɹkən stʃɹits ðət wɝ ðɛɹ hoʊm. ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ lɛft faɪv ə ðə θʌɡz dɛd, bʌɾ oʊnli wʌn ə hɪz mɛn wundəd. mæt sɛn hɑɹvəl əweɪ wɪð ə ɡɑɹɾ ə tu.

He ended up needing them three more times through the hour, each time scaring away a larger group of thugs. The last time, the Band and he actually clashed with the assassins. The thugs were no match for trained soldiers, even on the darkened streets that were their home. The exchange left five of the thugs dead, but only one of his men wounded. Mat sent Harvell away with a guard of two.

ɪt ɡɹu leɪɾɝ ən leɪɾɝ. mæt bɪɡæn tə wɝi ðəɾ i wəɾ əv tə ɹɪpit ðɪs æk ðə nɛks naɪt, bʌt ðən i noʊɾəst sʌmwʌn stændɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ əhɛd. ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz wɝ wɛt fɹəm ə mɪstɪŋ ɝliɝ ɪn ðə naɪt, ən ðeɪ ɹəflɛktəd ðə slɪvɝd mun.

It grew later and later. Mat began to worry that he would have to repeat this act the next night, but then he noticed someone standing in the street ahead. The paving stones were wet from a misting earlier in the night, and they reflected the slivered moon.

mæt stɑpt, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz wɛpən tə hɪz saɪd. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt dɪteɪlz əbaʊt ðə fɪɡjɝ, bʌt ðə weɪ ɪt stʊd . . .

Mat stopped, lowering his weapon to his side. He could not make out details about the figure, but the way it stood . . .

"ju θɪŋk tə æmbʊʃ mi?" ðə ɡoʊləm æskt, saʊndɪŋ əmjuzd. "wɪð jəɹ mɛn u skwɪʃ ən ɹɪp, hu daɪ soʊ izəli, ɔlmoʊst əɾ ə tʌtʃ?"

"You think to ambush me?" the gholam asked, sounding amused. "With your men who squish and rip, who die so easily, almost at a touch?"

"aɪm taɪɝɾ ə biɪŋ tʃeɪst," mæt sɛd laʊdli.

"I'm tired of being chased," Mat said loudly.

"soʊ jə dɪlɪvɝ jɝsɛlf tə mi? wʌɾ ə kaɪnd ɡɪft."

"So you deliver yourself to me? What a kind gift."

"ʃʊɹ," mæt sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz æsbændʒɹeɪ, fɑkshɛɾ ɑn ðə bæk kætʃɪŋ ðə munlaɪt. "dʒʌs maɪn ðə ʃɑɹp ɛdʒəz."

"Sure," Mat said, lowering his asbandarei, foxhead on the back catching the moonlight. "Just mind the sharp edges."

ðə θɪŋ slɪd fɔɹwɝd, ən mæts mɛn lɪt læntɝnz. ðə mɛn ə ðə bæn sɛt ðə læntɝnz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðən bækt əweɪ, ə fju ʌv əm dæʃɪŋ ɔf tə dɪlɪvɝ mɛsədʒəz. ðeɪ hæd stʃɹɪkt ɔɹɾɝz nɑt tə ɪntɝfɪɹ. tənaɪt wəd pɹɑbli stʃɹeɪn ðɛɹ oʊðz tə hɪm ɑn ðæt.

The thing slid forward, and Mat's men lit lanterns. The men of the Band set the lanterns on the ground, then backed away, a few of them dashing off to deliver messages. They had strict orders not to interfere. Tonight would probably strain their oaths to him on that.

mæt plæntəd hɪmsɛlf ən weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə ɡoʊləm. oʊnli ə hɪɹoʊ tʃɑɹdʒd ə bis laɪk ðæt, ən i wɑz noʊ blʌɾi hɪɹoʊ. ðoʊ hɪz mɛn wəd bi tʃɹaɪ- ɪŋ tə klɪɹ əweɪ ɛniwʌn ɑn ðə stʃɹits, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ði ɛɹiə ɛmpti soʊ noʊbɑdi wəd skɛɹ ðə ɡoʊləm əweɪ. ðət wɑz nɑt hɛɹoʊɪzəm. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn stupɪɾɪti, ðoʊ.

Mat planted himself and waited for the gholam. Only a hero charged a beast like that, and he was no bloody hero. Though his men would be try- ing to clear away anyone on the streets, trying to keep the area empty so nobody would scare the gholam away. That was not heroism. It might have been stupidity, though.

ðə ɡoʊləmz, fluəd muvməns θɹu læntɝnlaɪt ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs ðə ɹoʊd. mæt mɛɾ ɪt wɪð ə swip ə hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, bʌt ðə bis dæns tə ðə saɪd, izəli ɪveɪɾɪŋ hɪm. blʌɾi æʃəz, bʌt ðə θɪŋ wɑz fæst! ɪt ɹitʃt aʊt, swaɪpɪŋ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ wɪð ðə naɪf ɪt hɛld.

The gholam's, fluid movements threw lanternlight shadows across the road. Mat met it with a sweep of his ashandarei, but the beast danced to the side, easily evading him. Bloody ashes, but the thing was fast! It reached out, swiping at the front of the ashandarei with the knife it held.

mæt jæŋk ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ bæk, nɑt lɛɾɪŋ ðə mɑnstɝ kʌt ðə mədæljən fɹi. ɪt dænst ɝaʊn mæt, ən i spʌn, steɪɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹɪŋ ə læntɝnz. hi hæd tʃoʊzən ə ɹɛləɾɪvli waɪd stʃɹit, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ ðət deɪ ɪn ði æliweɪ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ wɛɹ ðə ɡoʊləm hæd nɪɹli teɪkən ɪm ɪn kloʊs kɔɹɾɝz.

Mat yanked the ashandarei back, not letting the monster cut the medallion free. It danced around Mat, and he spun, staying inside the ring of lanterns. He had chosen a relatively wide street, remembering with a shiver that day in the alleyway of Ebou Dar where the gholam had nearly taken him in close quarters.

ðə bist slɪd fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn, ən mæt faɪntɪd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn. hi ɔlmoʊs mɪskælkjəleɪɾɪd, bʌt twɪstəd ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn taɪm tə slæp ðə ɡoʊləm wɪð ðə flæɾ ə ðə wɛpən. ðə mədæljən lɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪs əz ɪt tʌtʃt ðə ɡoʊləmz ɑɹm.

The beast slid forward again, and Mat feinted, drawing it in. He almost miscalculated, but twisted the ashandarei in time to slap the gholam with the flat of the weapon. The medallion let out a hiss as it touched the gholam's arm.

ðə ɡoʊləm kɝst ən bækt əweɪ. weɪvɝɪŋ læntɝnlaɪɾ ɪluməneɪɾəd ɪts fitʃɝz, livɪŋ pɑkəts ə dɑɹknəs ən pɑkəts ə laɪt. ɪt wɑz smaɪlɪŋ əɡɛn, dɪspaɪt ðə wɪsp ə smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪts ɑɹm. bɪfɔɹ, mæt hæd θɔt ðɪs kɹitʃɝz feɪs ənɹɪmɑɹkəbəl, bʌɾ ɪn ði ənivən laɪt -  ən wɪð ðət smaɪl - ɪt tʊk ɑn ə tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ kæst. mɔɹ æŋɡjəlɝ, ɹəflɛktəd læntɝnlaɪt meɪkɪŋ ɪts aɪz ɡloʊ laɪk taɪni jɛloʊ fleɪmz kənsum baɪ ðə dɑɹknəs ʌv ɪts sɑkəts.

The gholam cursed and backed away. Wavering lanternlight illuminated its features, leaving pockets of darkness and pockets of light. It was smiling again, despite the wisp of smoke rising from its arm. Before, Mat had thought this creature's face unremarkable, but in the uneven light -  and with that smile - it took on a terrifying cast. More angular, reflected lanternlight making its eyes glow like tiny yellow flames consumed by the darkness of its sockets.

nɑndɪskɹɪp baɪ deɪ, ə hɔɹɝ baɪ naɪt. ðɪs θɪŋ hæd slɔɾɝd taɪlɪn waɪl ʃi leɪ hɛlpləs.

Nondescript by day, a horror by night. This thing had slaughtered Tylin while she lay helpless.

mæt ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. ðən i ətækt.

Mat gritted his teeth. Then he attacked.

ɪt wɑz ə blʌɾi stupəd θɪŋ tə du. ðə ɡoʊləm wɑz fæstɝ ðən i wɑz, ən mæt hæd noʊ aɪdiə ɪf ðə fɑkshɛd kəd kɪl ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. hi ətækt ɛniweɪ. hi ətæk fəɹ taɪlɪn, fəɹ ðə mɛn hid lɔs tə ðɪs hɔɹɝ. hi ətækt kəz i hæd noʊ ʌðɝ ɑpʃən. wən jə ɹɪli wɑntəd tə si wʌɾ ə mæn wɑz wɝθ, jə bækt ɪm ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ ən meɪɾ ɪm faɪt fəɹ ɪz laɪf.

It was a bloody stupid thing to do. The gholam was faster than he was, and Mat had no idea if the foxhead could kill it or not. He attacked anyway. He attacked for Tylin, for the men he'd lost to this horror. He attacked because he had no other option. When you really wanted to see what a man was worth, you backed him into a corner and made him fight for his life.

mæt wɑz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ naʊ. blʌɾid ən hɛɹid. hi nu ðɪs θɪŋ wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli faɪn hɪm  - ɔɹ, wɝs, faɪn tuɑn əɹ oʊlvɝ. ɪt wɑz ðə kaɪn əɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən wɛɹ ə sɛnsəbəl mæn wəɾ əv ɹʌn.

Mat was in the corner now. Bloodied and harried. He knew this thing would eventually find him  - or, worse, find Tuon or Olver. It was the kind or situation where a sensible man would have run.

bʌɾ i wɑz ə blʌɾi ful ɪnstɛd. steɪɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi kəz ʌv ən oʊθ tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? wɛl, ɪf i daɪd, hi wəd ɡoʊ aʊt wɪð wɛpən ɪn hænd.

But he was a bloody fool instead. Staying in the city because of an oath to an Aes Sedai? Well, if he died, he would go out with weapon in hand.

mæt bɪkeɪm ə swɝlɪŋ sɪkloʊn ə stil ən wʊd, jɛlɪŋ əz i ətækt. ðə ɡoʊləm, simɪŋ ʃɑkt, æktʃəli  bækt əweɪ. mæt slæmd ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪndə ɪts hænd, bɝnɪŋ ðə flɛʃ, ðən spʌn ən nɑk ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ɪts fɪŋɡɝz. ðə kɹitʃɝ lɛpt əweɪ, bʌt mæt lʌnʒd fɔɹwɝd, ɹæmɪŋ ðə bʌɾ ə hɪz spɪɹ bɪtwin ðə θɪŋz lɛɡz.

Mat became a swirling cyclone of steel and wood, yelling as he attacked. The gholam, seeming shocked, actually backed away. Mat slammed his ashandarei into its hand, burning the flesh, then spun and knocked the dagger from its fingers. The creature leaped away, but Mat lunged forward, ramming the butt of his spear between the thing's legs.

ɪt wɛn daʊn. ɪts moʊʃənz wɝ fluəd, ən ɪt kɑɾ ɪtsɛlf, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd ɡoʊ daʊn. əz ɪt θɹu ɪtsɛlf tə ɪts fit, mæt slæʃt ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ % bleɪɾ əɾ ɪts hil. hi nitli sɛvɝd ðə ɡoʊləm ɛs tɛndən, ən ɪf ðə θɪŋ hæd bɪn hjumən, ɪt wəɾ əv kəlæpst. ɪnstɛd, ɪt lændəd wɪθaʊɾ ivən ə wɪns ə peɪn, ən noʊ blʌd sip fɹi ʌv ðə kʌt.

It went down. Its motions were fluid, and it caught itself, but it did go down. As it threw itself to its feet, Mat slashed the ashandarei % blade at its heel. He neatly severed the gholam s tendon, and if the thing had been human, it would have collapsed. Instead, it landed without even a wince of pain, and no blood seeped free of the cut.

ɪt spʌn ən lʌnʒd ət mæt wɪð klɔd fɪŋɡɝz. hi wɑz fɔɹs tə stʌmbəl bæk, swɪŋɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ tə wɔɹɾ ɪɾ əweɪ. ðə kɹitʃɝ ɡɹɪn ət hɪm.

It spun and lunged at Mat with clawed fingers. He was forced to stumble back, swinging the ashandarei to ward it away. The creature grinned at him.

ðɛn, ɑdli, ɪt tɝn ən ɹæn.

Then, oddly, it turned and ran.

mæt kɝst. hæd sʌmθɪŋ skɛɹɾ ɪɾ əweɪ? bʌt noʊ, ɪt wɑz nɑt fliɪŋ ɪt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ ɪz mɛn!

Mat cursed. Had something scared it away? But no, it was not fleeing It was going for his men!

"ɹitʃɹit!" mæt kɔld ət ðɛm. "bæk! bɝn ju, jə blʌɾi mɑnstɝ. aɪm hɪɹ! faɪt mi!"

"Retreat!" Mat called at them. "Back! Burn you, you bloody monster. I'm here! Fight me!"

ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə bæn skæɾɝd əɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ tælmɑnz hʌŋ bæk, wɛɹɪŋ ə ɡɹɪm ɪkspɹɛʃən. ðə ɡoʊləm læft, bʌt dɪd nɑt tʃeɪs daʊn ðə soʊlʒɝz. ɪnstɛd, ðə θɪŋ kɪkt oʊvɝ ðə fɝs læntɝn, kɑzɪŋ ɪt tə wɪŋk aʊt. ɪt ɹæn ɝaʊn ðə sɝkəl, kɪkɪŋ əɾ itʃ wʌn, plʌnʒɪŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ ɪndə dɑɹknəs.

The members of the Band scattered at his orders, though Talmanes hung back, wearing a grim expression. The gholam laughed, but did not chase down the soldiers. Instead, the thing kicked over the first lantern, causing it to wink out. It ran around the circle, kicking at each one, plunging the street into darkness.

blʌɾi æʃəz! mæt tʃeɪst æftɝ ðə kɹitʃɝ. ɪf ɪt mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɔl ə ðoʊz laɪts aʊt, wɪð ðət klaʊd kʌvɝ, mæt wəd bi lɛft faɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ əneɪbəl tə si!

Bloody ashes! Mat chased after the creature. If it managed to get all of those lights out, with that cloud cover, Mat would be left fighting it unable to see!

tælmɑnz - bleɪɾəntli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪz oʊn seɪfti - lɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən snætʃt ɪz læntɝn ʌp tə pɹətɛkt ɪt. hi flɛd daʊn ðə stʃɹit, ən mæt kɝst əz ðə ɡoʊləm tʃeɪst æftɝ.

Talmanes - blatantly ignoring his own safety - leaped forward and snatched his lantern up to protect it. He fled down the street, and Mat cursed as the gholam chased after.

mæt dæʃt bɪhaɪn ðɛm. tælmɑnz hæɾ ə ɡʊd lɛd, bʌt ðə ɡoʊləm wɑz soʊ kwɪk. ɪt nɪɹli ɡɑt tə hɪm, ən tælmɑnz dʒɝk tə ðə saɪd, bækɪŋ ʌp ðə stɛps ʌv ə nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋ. ðə mɑnstɝ lʌnʒd fəɹ hɪm, ən tælmɑnz stʌmbəl bækwɝɾ əz mæt ɹæn təwɔɹɾ əm fəɹ ɔl i wɑz wɝθ.

Mat dashed behind them. Talmanes had a good lead, but the gholam was so quick. It nearly got to him, and Talmanes jerked to the side, backing up the steps of a nearby building. The monster lunged for him, and Talmanes stumbled backward as Mat ran toward them for all he was worth.

ðə læntɝn fɛl fɹəm tælmɑnz' fɪŋɡɝz ən splæʃt ɔɪl əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. ðə dʒɹaɪ wʊd keɪm əlaɪt, tʌŋz ə fleɪm ɹɪpəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə læmp ɔɪl, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡoʊləm. ɪt lɛp fəɹ tælmɑnz.

The lantern fell from Talmanes' fingers and splashed oil across the front of the building. The dry wood came alight, tongues of flame rippling across the lamp oil, illuminating the gholam. It leaped for Talmanes.

mæt θɹu hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ.

Mat threw his ashandarei.

ðə bɹɔd-bleɪɾɪd spɪɹ wɑz nɑt mɛn fəɹ θɹoʊɪŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ əv ə naɪf hændi. hi eɪm fəɹ ðə ɡoʊlɛɹɪs hɛd. wʌn wəɾ əv nɛvɝ noʊn ðæt, fəɹ i mɪs pɪɾɪfəli. fɔɹtʃənətli, ðə wɛpən dɪp daʊn ən pæs bɪtwin ðə ɡoʊləmz lɛɡz.

The broad-bladed spear was not meant for throwing, but he did not have a knife handy. He aimed for the gholairis head. One would have never known that, for he missed pitifully. Fortunately, the weapon dipped down and passed between the gholam's legs.

ðə mɑnstɝ tʃɹɪpt, θəɾɪŋ hɛvəli tə ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. tælmɑnz skɹæmbəl bæk ʌp ðə stɛps ə ðə naʊ-bleɪzɪŋ bɪldɪŋ.

The monster tripped, thudding heavily to the paving stones. Talmanes scrambled back up the steps of the now-blazing building.

blɛs ðɪs lʌk ə maɪn, mæt θɔt.

Bless this luck of mine, Mat thought.

ðə ɡoʊləm stʊɾ ʌp ən meɪɾ ə moʊʃən tə fɑloʊ tælmɑnz, bʌt ðən wʌnʊk daʊn ət wʌt hæd tʃɹɪpt ɪt. ðə kɹitʃɝ lʊkt ət mæt wɪð ə wɪkəd ɡɹɪn, hæf ɪts feɪs kæst ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə bɝnɪŋ bɪldɪŋ. ðə kɹitʃɝ pɪkt ʌp mæts æʃhændʒɹeɪ - fɑkshɛd mədæljən stɪl taɪd tə ðə fɹʌnt - ðən wɪpt ɪts hæn tə ðə saɪd, tɔsɪŋ ðə wɛpən əweɪ. ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ kɹæʃt θɹu ə wɪndoʊ ən pæst ɪndə ðə bɝnɪŋ bɪldɪŋ. læmps spɑɹkt ɑn ɪnsaɪd, əz ɪf ðoʊz lɪvɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli naʊ noʊɾɪk-ɪŋ ðə faɪt hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ pɹɑksɪməɾi. tælmɑnz ɡeɪv mæt ə lʊk, ən ðeɪ mɛɾ aɪz. ðə kɛɹhinɪn mæn θɹu hɪmsɛlf əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə bɝnɪŋ bɪldɪŋ ən bɹoʊk ɪn. ðə ɡoʊləm spʌn ɑn mæt, bæklɪt baɪ ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ fleɪmz. ðeɪ bleɪz kwɪkli, ən mæts hɑɹt θʌmpt wɪð əlɑɹm əz ðə kɹitʃɝ keɪm fəɹ hɪm, ənnətʃɝəli fæst. mæt ɹitʃt ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkəts wɪð swɛɾi fɪŋɡɝz. ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡoʊləm ɹitʃt ɪm - hænz ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ mæts nɛk - mæt pʊl sʌmθɪŋ aʊt wɪð itʃ hænd, slæmɪŋ əm fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ðə ɡoʊləmz pɑmz. hɪsɪŋ ɹæŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, laɪk mit biɪŋ pleɪst ɑn ə ɡɹɪl, ən ðə ɡoʊləm skɹitʃt ɪn peɪn. ɪt stʌmbəld, waɪd-aɪd, əz ɪt lʊkt ət mæt.

The gholam stood up and made a motion to follow Talmanes, but then 1ooked down at what had tripped it. The creature looked at Mat with a wicked grin, half its face cast in the light of the burning building. The creature picked up Mat's ashandarei - foxhead medallion still tied to the front - then whipped its hand to the side, tossing the weapon away. The ashandarei crashed through a window and passed into the burning building. Lamps sparked on inside, as if those living there were only now notic-ing the fight happening in their proximity. Talmanes gave Mat a look, and they met eyes. The Cairhienin man threw himself against the door into the burning building and broke in. The gholam spun on Mat, backlit by the growing flames. They blazed quickly, and Mat's heart thumped with alarm as the creature came for him, unnaturally fast. Mat reached into his coat pockets with sweaty fingers. Right before the gholam reached him - hands going for Mat's neck - Mat pulled something out with each hand, slamming them forward into the gholam's palms. Hissing rang in the air, like meat being placed on a grill, and the gholam screeched in pain. It stumbled, wide-eyed, as it looked at Mat.

hu hɛld ə fɑkshɛd mədæljən ɪn itʃ hænd.

Who held a foxhead medallion in each hand.

hi wɪpt əm aʊt, itʃ hɛld ɑn ə lɔŋ, θɪk tʃeɪn, spɪnɪŋ ðɛm. ðə mədæljənz kɑt faɪɹlaɪt, simɪŋ tə ɡloʊ əz mæt wɪpt əm ət ðə ɡoʊləm, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ði ɑɹm.

He whipped them out, each held on a long, thick chain, spinning them. The medallions caught firelight, seeming to glow as Mat whipped them at the gholam, striking it on the arm.

ðə kɹitʃɝ haʊld, bækɪŋ ʌp ənʌðɝ stɛp. "haʊ?" ɪt dɪmændəd. "haʊ!"

The creature howled, backing up another step. "How?" it demanded. "How!"

"doʊn ɹaɪtli noʊ maɪsɛlf." ɪleɪn hæd sɛɾ əɹ kɑpiz wɝn pɝfəkt, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðeɪ dɪd ðə dʒɑb wɛl ɪnʌf. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ hɝt ðə ɡoʊləm, hi dɪdn kɛɹ əbaʊt ðɛɹ ʌðɝ əbɪləɾiz. mæt ɡɹɪnd, spɪnɪŋ ðə sɛkən mədæljən fɔɹwɝd. "ɡɛs aɪ dʒʌst ɡɑt lʌki."

"Don't rightly know myself." Elayne had said her copies weren't perfect, but it seemed they did the job well enough. So long as they hurt the gholam, he didn't care about their other abilities. Mat grinned, spinning the second medallion forward. "Guess I just got lucky."

ðə ɡoʊləm ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ðən stʌmbəld ʌp ðə stɛps təwɔɹd ðə bɝnɪŋ bɪldɪŋ. ɪt dæʃt ɪnsaɪd, pɝhæps dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə fli. mæt wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛɾ ɪɾ ɪskeɪp, nɑt ðɪs taɪm. hi tʃɑɹdʒd ɪɾ ʌp ðə stɛps ən dʌk θɹu ðə fleɪmɪŋ dɔɹweɪ, ɹitʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə hæn əz tælmɑnz tɔst ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ tə hɪm fɹəm ə saɪd hɔlweɪ.

The gholam glared at him, then stumbled up the steps toward the burning building. It dashed inside, perhaps deciding to flee. Mat was not about to let it escape, not this time. He charged it up the steps and ducked through the flaming doorway, reaching out a hand as Talmanes tossed his ashandarei to him from a side hallway.

mæt kɑt ðə wɛpən, livɪŋ ðə mədæljənz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz fɹɑɹmz. ðə ɡoʊləm spʌn ɑn hɪm; ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bɝnɪŋ, ðə hit fɹəm ðə saɪdz ən əbʌv əpɹɛsɪv. smoʊk laɪn ðə silɪŋ. tælmɑnz kɔft, ə kɝtʃəf hɛl tə hɪz feɪs.

Mat caught the weapon, leaving the medallions wrapped around his forearms. The gholam spun on him; the hallway was already burning, the heat from the sides and above oppressive. Smoke lined the ceiling. Talmanes coughed, a kerchief held to his face.

ðə ɡoʊləm tɝn ɑn mæt, snɑɹlɪŋ ən ətækɪŋ. mæt mɛt ðə bist ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə waɪd hɔlweɪ, bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ tə blɑk ðə ɡoʊləm'?, klɔlaɪk hænz. ðə bʌɾ ə mæts æʃhændʒɹeɪ hæd bɪn sɪŋʒd fɹəm sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə faɪɝ, ən ðə wʊd smoʊldɝɾ ət ði ɛnd. ɪt lɛft ə tʃɹeɪl ə smoʊk ɪn ði ɛɹ.

The gholam turned on Mat, snarling and attacking. Mat met the beast in the middle of the wide hallway, bringing up his ashandarei to block the gholam'?, clawlike hands. The butt of Mat's ashandarei had been singed from sitting in the fire, and the wood smoldered at the end. It left a trail of smoke in the air.

hi ətæk fəɹ ɔl i wɑz wɝθ, spɪnɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ, ðə bæk ɛn livɪŋ ə wɝl ə smoʊk ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə ɡoʊləm tʃɹaɪd tə stʃɹaɪk ət hɪm, bʌt mæt dʒɹɑp ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ wɪð wʌn hæn ən flʌŋ wʌn ə ðə mədæljənz laɪk ə naɪf, hɪɾɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝ ɪn ðə feɪs. ɪt haʊld ən stʌmbəl bæk, feɪs bɝn ən smoʊkɪŋ. mæt stɛp fɔɹwɝd, slæmɪŋ ði ɛn ə ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ əɡɛns ðə mədæljən əz ɪt hɪt ðə flɔɹ, flɪpɪŋ ɪt bæk ʌp ən hɪɾɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝ əɡɛn.

He attacked for all he was worth, spinning the ashandarei, the back end leaving a whirl of smoke around him. The gholam tried to strike at him, but Mat dropped the ashandarei with one hand and flung one of the medallions like a knife, hitting the creature in the face. It howled and stumbled back, face burned and smoking. Mat stepped forward, slamming the end of the ashandarei against the medallion as it hit the floor, flipping it back up and hitting the creature again.

hi pʊʃt fɔɹwɝd, slæʃɪŋ wɪð ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ, ən sɛvɹəl ə ðə kɹitʃɝz fɪŋɡɝz flu fɹi.

He pushed forward, slashing with the ashandarei, and several of the creature's fingers flew free.

ʃʊɹ, ɪt dɪd nɑt bliɾ ən dɪd nɑt sim tə fil peɪn fɹəm ɔɹɾənɛɹi wunz, bʌt ðət wəd sloʊ ɪɾ ə bɪt. ðə ɡoʊləm ɹəkʌvɝd, hɪsɪŋ, aɪz waɪd wɪð æŋɡɝ. ɪts smaɪl wɑz ɡɔn naʊ. ɪt lɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ə blɝ, bʌt mæt spʌn ən slaɪs daʊn ðə kɹitʃɝz tæn ʃɝt, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ɪts tʃɛst. ðən i wɪp ðə sɛkən mədæljən tə ðə saɪd, hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡoʊləm əz ɪt klɔɾ əɾ ɪz ɑɹm, slaɪsɪŋ ðə skɪn ən spɹeɪɪŋ blʌɾ əkɹɔs ðə wɔl.

Sure, it did not bleed and did not seem to feel pain from ordinary wounds, but that would slow it a bit. The gholam recovered, hissing, eyes wide with anger. Its smile was gone now. It leaped forward in a blur, but Mat spun and sliced down the creature's tan shirt, exposing its chest. Then he whipped the second medallion to the side, hitting the gholam as it clawed at his arm, slicing the skin and spraying blood across the wall.

mæt ɡɹʌntɪd. ðə ɡoʊləm haʊld ən stʌmbəl bæk, fɑɹðɝ daʊn ðə bɝnɪŋ hɔlweɪ. mæt wɑz swɛɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə hit, fɹəm ði ɪɡzɝʃən. mæt kəd nɑt faɪt ðɪs kɹitʃɝ. nɑt fəɹ lɔŋ. ðət dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hi pʊʃt fɔɹwɝd, lɛɾɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ bɪkʌm ə blɝ. hi slæp ðə flæɾ ʌv ɪt -  wɪð ðə mədæljən - əɡɛns ðə ɡoʊləm. wən ðə bist ɹəkʌvɝd, hi flʌŋ ðə sɛkən mədæljən əɾ ɪts feɪs, meɪkɪŋ ɪt dʌk. bʌt ðən i kɪk ðə θɝd wʌn ʌp tə hɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə nɛk. hi lɛf laɪnz ə smoʊk ɪn ði ɛɹ əz i spʌn ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ, ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn tu hænz əɡɛn. ði ɛn ə hɪz wɛpən ɡloʊɾ ən smoʊldɝd. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf jɛlɪŋ ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ.

Mat grunted. The gholam howled and stumbled back, farther down the burning hallway. Mat was sweating from the heat, from the exertion. Mat could not fight this creature. Not for long. That did not matter. He pushed forward, letting his ashandarei become a blur. He slapped the flat of it -  with the medallion - against the gholam. When the beast recovered, he flung the second medallion at its face, making it duck. But then he kicked the third one up to hit it on the neck. He left lines of smoke in the air as he spun the ashandarei, grabbing it in two hands again. The end of his weapon glowed and smoldered. He found himself yelling in the Old Tongue.

"æl dɪvəl, æl kaɪsɝi, æl mæʃi!" fəɹ laɪt, ɡlɔɹi, ən lʌv!

"Al dival, al kiserai, al mashi!" For light, glory, and love!

ðə ɡoʊləm stɛp bæk, snɑɹlɪŋ ət ðə bɝɑʒ. ɪt lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪts ʃoʊldɝ, simɪŋ tə noʊɾəs sʌmθɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, bʌt mæts ətæk dʒɹu ɪts ətɛnʃən bæk.

The gholam stepped back, snarling at the barrage. It looked over its shoulder, seeming to notice something behind, but Mat's attack drew its attention back.

"teɪdeɪʃɝ!" tʃɹu blʌɾ ə bæɾəl!

"Tai'daishar!" True Blood of Battle!

mæt fɔɹs ðə kɹitʃɝ təwɔɹɾ ən oʊpən dɔɹweɪ ət ðə bæk ə ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə ɹum bɪɑnd wɑz ɪntaɪɝli dɑɹk. noʊ laɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝz ɹəflɛktəɾ ɔf wɔlz ðɛɹ.

Mat forced the creature toward an open doorway at the back of the hallway. The room beyond was entirely dark. No light of the fires reflected off walls there.

"kæɹɑi mænʃɪmaɪə taɪlɪn. kæɹɑi ən mænʃɪmaɪə neɪlzin. kæɹɑi ən mæn-ʃimaɪə aɪɛndæn!"

"Carai manshimaya Tylin. Carai an manshimaya Nalesean. Carai an man-shimaya ayend'an!"

ɑnɝ ə maɪ bleɪd fəɹ taɪlɪn. ɑnɝ ə maɪ bleɪd fəɹ neɪlzin. ɑnɝ ə maɪ bleɪd fəɹ ðə fɔlən.

Honor of my blade for Tylin. Honor of my blade for Nalesean. Honor of my blade for the fallen.

ðə kɔl ə vɛnʒəns.

The call of vengeance.

ðə ɡoʊləm bækt ɪndə ðə dɑɹkən ɹum, stɛpɪŋ ɑntu ə boʊn waɪt flɔɹ, aɪz flɪkɝɪŋ daʊn.

The gholam backed into the darkened room, stepping onto a bone white floor, eyes flickering down.

teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, mæt lɛp θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ wɪð ə faɪnəl bɝst ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ən slæm ðə smoʊldɝɪŋ bʌɾ ə hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪndə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kɹitʃɝz hɛd. ə spɹeɪ ʌv spɑɹks ən æʃ ɪksploʊɾəd ɝaʊn ɪts feɪs. ðə kɹitʃɝ kɝst ən stʌmbəl tə ðə ɹaɪt.

Taking a deep breath, Mat leaped through the doorway with a final burst of strength and slammed the smoldering butt of his ashandarei into the side of the creature's head. A spray of sparks and ash exploded around its face. The creature cursed and stumbled to the right.

ən ðɛɹ, ɪt nɪɹli stɛpt ɔf ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə plætfɔɹm hæŋɪŋ əbʌv ən ɪkspænsɪv vɔɪd. ðə ɡoʊləm hɪst ɪn æŋɡɝ, hæŋɪŋ wɪð wʌn lɛɡ oʊvɝ ðə vɔɪd, fleɪlɪŋ tə kip ɪts bæləns.

And there, it nearly stepped off the edge of a platform hanging above an expansive void. The gholam hissed in anger, hanging with one leg over the void, flailing to keep its balance.

fɹəm ðɪs saɪd, ðə dɔɹweɪ ɪndə ðə ɹum wɑz ɹɪŋ baɪ ə ɡloʊɪŋ waɪt laɪt - ði ɛdʒəz ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ meɪd fəɹ skɪmɪŋ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf vu kən daɪ," mæt sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ hoʊp tə ðə laɪt ðət jə kænt." hi ɹeɪzd ə buɾ ən slæmd ɪɾ ɪndə ðə θɪŋz bæk, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪɾ ɔf ðə plætfɔɹm ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ɪt fɛl, twɪstɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð ə hɔɹɝ.

From this side, the doorway into the room was ringed by a glowing white light - the edges of a gateway made for Skimming. "I don't know if vou can die," Mat said softly. "I hope to the Light that you can't." He raised a boot and slammed it into the thing's back, throwing it off the platform into the darkness. It fell, twisting in the air, looking up at him with a horror.

"aɪ hoʊp jə kæn daɪ," mæt sɛd, "bɪkɔz aɪm gɑnə ɛndʒɔɪ ðə θɔɾ ə jə fɔlɪŋ θɹu ðət blæknəs fɝɛvɝ, jə mɪsbəɡɑɾən sʌn ʌv ə ɡoʊts dʒɹɑpɪŋz." mæt spɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd, sɛndɪŋ ə bɪɾ ə blʌɾi spɪɾəl daʊn, plʌməɾɪŋ æftɝ ðə ɡoʊləm. boʊθ dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə blæknəs bɪloʊ.

"I hope you can't die," Mat said, "because I'm going to enjoy the thought of you falling through that blackness forever, you misbegotten son of a goat's droppings." Mat spit over the side, sending a bit of bloody spittle down, plummeting after the gholam. Both disappeared into the blackness below.

sumeɪkoʊ wɔkt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðə staʊt kɪnswʊmən hæd lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ ən ði ɛɹ ʌv ə wʊmən u dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ɔɹɾɝd əbaʊt. nɪɹli ɛvɹi wʊmən hæd ðət seɪm ɛɹ. ʃid bɪn stændɪŋ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, tə ðə saɪd wɛɹ ʃi wəd bi ənsin fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪ. ʃi hæd tə bi ðəɹ tə meɪnteɪn ðə waɪt plætfɔɹm, wɪtʃ wɑz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ bʊk. ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm.

Sumeko walked up beside him. The stout Kinswoman had long dark hair and the air of a woman who did not like being ordered about. Nearly every woman had that same air. She'd been standing just inside the gateway, to the side where she would be unseen from the hallway. She had to be there to maintain the white platform, which was in the shape of a large book. She raised an eyebrow at him.

"θæŋks fəɹ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ," mæt sɛd, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, ðə bʌt stɪl tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ə θɪn laɪn ə smoʊk. ʃid meɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə pæləs, juzɪŋ ɪt tə tʃɹævəl tə ðɪs pɔɪn ən oʊpən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. ðeɪd hoʊp ðət wəd kip ðə ɡoʊləm fɹəm filɪŋ əɹ tʃænəl, əz ʃid meɪd ðə wivz ɪn ðə pæləs.

"Thanks for the gateway," Mat said, shouldering his ashandarei, the butt still trailing a thin line of smoke. She'd made the gateway from inside the palace, using it to travel to this point and open the gateway in the hallway. They'd hoped that would keep the gholam from feeling her channel, as she'd made the weaves in the palace.

sumeɪkoʊ snɪft. təɡɛðɝ, ðə tu wɔkt aʊt θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ən ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ. sɛvɹəl ə ðə bænd wɝ hɝidli pʊɾɪŋ aʊt ðə faɪɝ. tælmɑnz ɹʌʃt ʌp tə mæt əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃt, əkʌmpənid baɪ ənʌðɝ ə ðə kɪnswɪmən, dʒulənjə.

Sumeko sniffed. Together, the two walked out through the gateway and into the building. Several of the Band were hurriedly putting out the fire. Talmanes rushed up to Mat as the gateway vanished, accompanied by another of the Kinswomen, Julanya.

"ju ʃʊɹ ðət dɑɹknəs ɡoʊz ɑn fɝɛvɝ?" mæt æskt. dʒulənjə wɑz ə plʌmp, pɹɪɾi wʊmən u wʊɾə fɪt naɪsli ɑn mæts ni. ðə waɪɾ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ dɪd nɑt dɪtʃɹæk fɹəm əɹ pɹɪɾinəs əɾ ɔl.

"You sure that darkness goes on forever?" Mat asked. Julanya was a plump, pretty woman who would have fit nicely on Mat's knee. The white in her hair did not detract from her prettiness at all.

"nɪɹ əz wi kən tɛl, ɪt dʌz," sumeɪkoʊ sɛd. "ðɪs wɑz kwaɪt nɪɹli bʌŋɡəld, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən.

"Near as we can tell, it does," Sumeko said. "This was quite nearly bungled, Matrim Cauthon.

ðə θɪŋ dɪdn sim sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. aɪ θɪŋk ɪt sɛnst ɪɾ ɛniweɪ."

The thing didn't seem surprised by the gateway. I think it sensed it anyway."

'stɪl mænədʒ tə faɪɾ ɪɾ ɔf ðə plætfɔɹm," mæt sɛd.

'Still managed to fight it off the platform," Mat said.

"bɛɹli. jə ʃʊɾə lɛɾ əs dil wɪð ðə bist." wʊdn əv wɝkt," mæt sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə wɛɾɪd kɝtʃəf fɹəm tælmɑnz. sumeɪkoʊ ɡlænst əɾ ɪz ɑɹm, bʌt mæt dɪdn æsk fəɹ hilɪŋ. ðət kʌt wəd hil ɹaɪt naɪsli. maɪɾ ivən əv ə ɡʊd skɑɹ. skɑɹz ɪmpɹɛs moʊst wɪmən, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɑn ðə feɪs. wʌd tuɑn θɪŋk ə ðɛm?

"Barely. You should have let us deal with the beast." Wouldn't have worked," Mat said, taking a wetted kerchief from Talmanes. Sumeko glanced at his arm, but Mat didn't ask for Healing. That cut would heal right nicely. Might even have a good scar. Scars impressed most women, so long as they were not on the face. What did Tuon think of them?

sumeɪkoʊ snɪft. "ðə pɹaɪɾ ə mɛn. də nɑt fɝɡɛt ðət wi lɔst səm ʌv əɹ oʊn tə ðət θɪŋ."

Sumeko sniffed. "The pride of men. Do not forget that we lost some of our own to that thing."

"æn aɪm ɡlæɾ aɪ kəd hɛlp jə ɡɛt ɹivɛnʒ," mæt sɛd. hi smaɪld ət hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt, ɪt hæd nɪɹli bɪn bʌŋɡəld. hi wɑz sɝɾən ðə ɡoʊləm hæd fɛl ðə kɪnswʊmən bɪɑn ðət dɔɹweɪ əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt fɔɹtʃənətli, ðoʊ, ðə θɪŋ hædn sim tə kənsɪɾɝ wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl tə bi ə θɹɛt.

"And I'm glad I could help you get revenge," Mat Said. He smiled at her, though she was right, it had nearly been bungled. He was certain the gholam had felt the Kinswoman beyond that doorway as they approached Fortunately, though, the thing hadn't seemed to consider woman who could channel to be a threat.

tælmɑnz hændəd mæt bæk ðə tu fɔlən mədæljənz. hi tʌkt əm əweɪ ən əntaɪd ðə wʌn ɑn ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, slɪpɪŋ ɪt bæk ɑntu hɪz nɛk. ðə kɪn wɑtʃt ðoʊz mədæljənz wɪð ə pɹɛɾətɔɹi hʌŋɡɝ. wɛl ðeɪ kəd də ðəɾ ɔl ðeɪ wɑntəd. hi ɪntɛndəd wʌn fəɹ oʊlvɝ ən ði ʌðɝ fəɹ tuɑn, wʌns i kəd faɪn hɝ.

Talmanes handed Mat back the two fallen medallions. He tucked them away and untied the one on his ashandarei, slipping it back onto his neck. The Kin watched those medallions with a predatory hunger. Well they could do that all they wanted. He intended one for Olver and the other for Tuon, once he could find her.

kæptən ɡaɪbɑn, bɝdʒɪts sɛkənd-ɪn-kəmænd, wɔkt ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ. "ðə bist ɪz dɛd?"

Captain Guybon, Birgitte's second-in-command, walked into the building. "The beast is dead?"

"noʊ," mæt sɛd, "bʌt kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ə kɹaʊn kɑntʃɹækt."

"No," Mat said, "but close enough for a Crown contract."

"kɹaʊn kɑntʃɹækt?" ɡaɪbɑn æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ju æsk ðə kwinz eɪɾ ɑn ðɪs ɪndɛvɝ. ðɪs wɑzn dʌn ɑn əɹ kɑntʃɹækt."

"Crown contract?" Guybon asked, frowning. "You asked the Queen's aid on this endeavor. This wasn't done on her contract."

"æktʃəli ," tælmɑnz sɛd, klɪɹɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt, "wi dʒʌst ɹɪd ðə sɪɾi ʌv ə mɝɾɝɝ u hæz teɪkən, ət læs kaʊnt, nɪɹli ə dʌzən ə hɝ sɪɾəzənz. wɝ ɛntaɪɾəld tə kɑmbæt peɪ, aɪ sɝmaɪz." hi sɛɾ ɪt wɪð ə kəmplitli stʃɹeɪt feɪs. blɛs ðə mæn.

"Actually," Talmanes said, clearing his throat, "we just rid the city of a murderer who has taken, at last count, nearly a dozen of her citizens. We're entitled to combat pay, I surmise." He said it with a completely straight face. Bless the man.

"blʌɾi ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd. stɑpɪŋ ðə ɡoʊləm ən ɡɛɾɪŋ peɪd fəɹ ɪt. ðət saʊndəd laɪk ə sʌni deɪ fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. hi tɔst ɪz kɝtʃəf tə ɡaɪbɑn ən wɔkt əweɪ, livɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə kɪnswɪmən u foʊldəd ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ən wɑtʃt wɪð dɪsplɛʒɝ. waɪ wɑz ɪɾ ə wʊmən kəd lʊk æŋɡɹi wɪð ə mæn ivən wən i hæd dʌn ɪɡzækli wʌɾ i hæd sɛɾ i wʊd, ɹɪskɪŋ ɪz nɛk ivən?

"Bloody right," Mat said. Stopping the gholam and getting paid for it. That sounded like a sunny day for a change. He tossed his kerchief to Guybon and walked away, leaving behind the Kinswomen who folded their arms and watched with displeasure. Why was it a woman could look angry with a man even when he had done exactly what he had said he would, risking his neck even?

"sɑɹi əbaʊt ðə faɪɝ, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd. "dɪdn min tə dʒɹɑp ðə læntɝn laɪk ðæt. aɪ noʊ aɪ wɑz dʒʌst səpoʊz tə liɾ ɪm ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ."

"Sorry about the fire, Mat," Talmanes said. "Didn't mean to drop the lantern like that. I know I was just supposed to lead him into the building."

"wɝkt aʊt faɪn," mæt sɛd, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə bʌɾ ə hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ. ðə dæmədʒ wɑz maɪnɝ.

"Worked out fine," Mat said, inspecting the butt of his ashandarei. The damage was minor.

ðeɪ hæd nɑt noʊn wɛɹ - əɹ ɪf - ðə ɡoʊləm wəɾ ətæk hɪm, bʌt ɡaɪbɑn hæd dʌn ɪz dʒɑb wɛl, ɡɛɾɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn aʊɾ ə ðə nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋz, ðən pɪkɪŋ ə hɔlweɪ ðət ðə kɪnswʊmən wəd meɪk ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪntu. hid sɛn ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə bæn tə tɛl tælmɑnz wɛɹ tə ɡoʊ.

They had not known where - or if - the gholam would attack him, but Guybon had done his job well, getting everyone out of the nearby buildings, then picking a hallway that the Kinswoman would make the gateway into. He'd sent a member of the Band to tell Talmanes where to go.

wɛl, ɪleɪn ən bɝdʒɪts aɪdiə wɪð ðə ɡeɪtweɪ hæd wɝkt aʊt, ivən ɪf ɪt hædn bɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪd plænd. ɪt wɑz stɪl bɛɾɝ ðən wʌt mæt hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə kʌm wɪð; hɪz oʊnli aɪdiə bæd bɪn tə tʃɹaɪ tə stʌf wʌn ə ðoʊz mədæljənz daʊn ðə ɡoʊləmz θɹoʊt.

Well, Elayne and Birgitte's idea with the gateway had worked out, even if it hadn't been the way they'd planned. It was still better than what Mat had been able to come with; his only idea bad been to try to stuff one of those medallions down the gholam's throat.

"lɛts kəlɛk sɛɾəl ən oʊlvɝ fɹəm ðɛɹ ɪn," mæt sɛd, "ænd ɡɛt bæk tə kæmp. ɪksaɪtməns oʊvɝ fəɹ naʊ. əbaʊt blʌɾi taɪm."

"Let's collect Setalle and Olver from their inn," Mat said, "and get back to camp. Excitement's over for now. About bloody time."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu


CHAPTER 32

eɪ stɔɹm ə laɪt


A Storm of Light

ðə sɪɾi ʌv mɛɹədɑn bɝnd. vaɪələnt, twɪstɪŋ kɑləmz ə smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm dʌzənz ə bɪldɪŋz.

The city of Maradon burned. Violent, twisting columns of smoke rose from dozens of buildings.

ðə kɛɹfəl sɪɾi plænɪŋ kɛp ðə faɪɝz fɹəm spɹɛɾɪŋ tu kwɪkli, bʌt dɪd nɑt stɑp əm ɪntaɪɝli.

The careful city planning kept the fires from spreading too quickly, but did not stop them entirely.

hjumən biɪŋz ən tɪndɝ. ðeɪ wɛn təɡɛðɝ.

Human beings and tinder. They went together.

ɪɾɝɑldi kɹaʊtʃt ɪnsaɪɾ ə bɹoʊkən bɪldɪŋ, ɹʌbəl tə hɪz lɛft, ə smɔl bæn ə sɑldəiənz tə hɪz ɹaɪt. hiɾ əbændən ðə pæləs ɝli ɑn; ɪt hæd bɪn swɔɹmd wɪð ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. hid lɛft ɪt pækt wɪð ɔl ði ɔɪl ðeɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪnd, ðən hæd ði æʃəmən sɛɾ ɪɾ əfleɪm, kɪlɪŋ hʌnʒɹədz ə tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz tʃɹæpt ɪnsaɪd.

Ituralde crouched inside a broken building, rubble to his left, a small band of Saldaeans to his right. He'd abandoned the palace early on; it had been swarmed with Shadowspawn. He'd left it packed with all the oil they'd been able to find, then had the Asha'man set it aflame, killing hundreds of Trollocs and Fades trapped inside.

hi ɡlænst aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ ʌv ɪz kɝən haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. hi cʊɾə swɔɹn hid sin ə pætʃ ə bɛɹ skaɪ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ, bʌt ði æʃ ən smoʊki heɪz ɪn ði ɛɹ meɪɾ ɪt dɪfəkəl tə tɛl. ə bɪldɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ bɝn soʊ ɪntɛnsli ðəɾ i kəd fil ðə hit θɹu ðə stoʊn.

He glanced out the window of his current hiding place. He could have sworn he'd seen a patch of bare sky out the window, but the ash and smoky haze in the air made it difficult to tell. A building nearby burned so intensely that he could feel the heat through the stone.

hi juz ðə smoʊk ən ðə faɪɝ. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn ə bæɾəlfild kəd bi ən ædvæntɪdʒ. ɪn ðɪs keɪs, wʌns joʊli hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðət ðə sɪɾi wɑz lɔst, ðeɪd stɑp dɪfɛndɪŋ ɪt. naʊ ðeɪ juz ðə sɪɾi əz ə kɪlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd.

He used the smoke and the fire. Almost everything on a battlefield could be an advantage. In this case, once Yoeli had accepted that the city was lost, they'd stopped defending it. Now they used the city as a killing ground.

ðə stʃɹits kɹieɪɾəd ə meɪz ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi - wɪð ðə hɛlp ə ðə sɑldəiənz - nu ən ɪz ɛnəmiz dɪd nɑt. ɛvɹi ɹuftɑp wɑz ə ɹɪdʒ tə ɡɪv haɪ ɡɹaʊnd, ɛvɹi æli ə sikɹəɾ ɪskeɪp ɹut, ɛvɹi oʊpən skwɛɹ ə pətɛnʃəl tʃɹæp.

The streets created a maze that Ituralde - with the help of the Saldaeans - knew and his enemies did not. Every rooftop was a ridge to give high ground, every alley a secret escape route, every open square a potential trap.

ðə tʃɹɑləks ən ðɛɹ kəmændɝz hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. ðeɪ əsum ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi kɛɹɾ əbaʊt pɹətɛktɪŋ ðə sɪɾi. ðeɪ mɪstʊk hɪm. ɔl i kɛɹɾ əbaʊt naʊ wɑz duɪŋ əz mʌtʃ dæmədʒ tə ðɛm əz pɑsəbəl. soʊ, hi juz ðɛɹ əsʌmpʃənz əɡɛns hɪm. jɛs, ðɛɹ ɑɹmi wɑz lɑɹdʒ. bʌɾ ɛni mæn u hæɾ ɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɹæts nu ðət ðə saɪz ə hɪz hæmɝ dɪdn mæɾɝ soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə ɹæts nu haʊ tə haɪd.

The Trollocs and their commanders had made a mistake. They assumed that Ituralde cared about protecting the city. They mistook him. All he cared about now was doing as much damage to them as possible. So, he used their assumptions against him. Yes, their army was large. But any man who had ever tried to kill rats knew that the size of his hammer didn't matter so long as the rats knew how to hide.

ə hɛzɪɾənt ɡɹup ə ðə kɹitʃɝz ʃʌfəl daʊn ðə blækən stʃɹiɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪɾɝɑldiz bɪldɪŋ.

A hesitant group of the creatures shuffled down the blackened street outside Ituralde's building.

ðə tʃɹɑləks snæpt ən huɾɪd wɛɹəli ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. səm snɪft ət ði ɛɹ, bʌt ðə smoʊk ɹuən ðɛɹ sɛns ə smɛl. ðeɪ kəmplitli mɪst ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪz smɔl bænd, dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə bɪldɪŋ.

The Trollocs snapped and hooted warily at one another. Some sniffed at the air, but the smoke ruined their sense of smell. They completely missed Ituralde and his small band, just inside the building.

hʊfbits ɹæŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə stʃɹit. ðə tʃɹɑləks bɪɡæn tə ʃaʊt, æɹəɾ ə ɡɹup hɝid tə ðə fɹʌnt, sɛɾɪŋ wɪkɪdli bɑɹb spɪɹz daʊn wɪð ðə bʌts əɡɛns ðə kɑbəlz. tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ðət wəd bi dɛθ fəɹ kævəlɹi. ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ lɝnɪŋ tə bi mɔɹ kɛɹfəl.

Hoofbeats rang on the other end of the street. The Trollocs began to shout, arid a group hurried to the front, setting wickedly barbed spears down with the butts against the cobbles. Charging that would be death for cavalry. The Trollocs were learning to be more careful.

bʌt ðeɪ wɝn lɝnɪŋ wɛl ɪnʌf. ðə kævəlɹi keɪm ɪndə vju, ɹɪvilɪŋ wʌn mæn liɾɪŋ ə ɡɹup ʌv wundəɾ ən ɪɡzɔstəd hɔɹsəz. ə dɪstʃɹækʃən.

But they weren't learning well enough. The cavalry came into view, revealing one man leading a group of wounded and exhausted horses. A distraction.

"naʊ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. ði ɑɹtʃɝz ɝaʊn ɪm spɹæŋ ʌp ən bɪɡæn ʃuɾɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊz ət ðə tʃɹɑləks. mɛni daɪd; ʌðɝz spʌn ən tʃɑɹdʒd.

"Now," Ituralde said. The archers around him sprang up and began shooting out the windows at the Trollocs. Many died; others spun and charged.

ən fɹəm ə saɪd stʃɹiɾ ə kævəlɹi tʃɑɹdʒ - ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz kʌvɝd wɪð ɹæɡz tə dæmpən saʊnd  - ɡæləpt aʊt, ðɛɹ əpɹoʊtʃ kʌvɝd baɪ ðə laʊɾɝ hʊvz ə ðə daɪvɝʒənɛɹi hɔɹsəz. ðə sɑldəiənz ɹɪp θɹu ðə tʃɹɑləks, tʃɹæmplɪŋ ən kɪlɪŋ.

And from a side street a cavalry charge - the horses' hooves covered with rags to dampen sound  - galloped out, their approach covered by the louder hooves of the diversionary horses. The Saldaeans ripped through the Trollocs, trampling and killing.

ði ɑɹtʃɝz wupt ən tʊk aʊt sɔɹdz ən æksiz tə fɪnɪʃ ɔf ðə wundəd tʃɹɑləks. noʊ feɪd wɪð ðɪs ɡɹup, blɛs ðə laɪt. ɪɾɝɑldi stʊɾ ʌp, ə wɛt hæŋkɝtʃɪf tə hɪz feɪs əɡɛns ðə smoʊk.

The archers whooped and took out swords and axes to finish off the wounded Trollocs. No Fade with this group, bless the Light. Ituralde stood up, a wet handkerchief to his face against the smoke.

hɪz wɪɹinəs - wʌns bɛɹid dip - wɑz sloʊli ɹisɝfəsɪŋ. hi wɑz wɝid ðət wən ɪt hɪt hɪm, hid dʒɹɑp ʌnkɑnʃəs. bæd fəɹ mɝæl, ðæt.

His weariness - once buried deep - was slowly resurfacing. He was worried that when it hit him, he'd drop unconscious. Bad for morale, that.

noʊ, hi θɔt, haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə smoʊk waɪl jəɹ hoʊm bɝnz, noʊɪŋ ðət ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ sloʊli pɛnɪŋ jə ɪn . . . ðæts bæd fəɹ mɝæl.

No, he thought, hiding in the smoke while your home burns, knowing that the Trollocs are slowly penning you in . . . that's bad for morale.

hɪz mɛn fɪnɪʃt ɔf ðə fɪst ə tʃɹɑləks, ðən heɪsən tə ənʌðɝ pɹi-dɪsaɪɾɪd bɪldɪŋ ðət ðeɪ kəd haɪɾ ɪn. ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ əbaʊt θɝɾi ɑɹtʃɝz ən ə kʌmpəni ʌv kævəlɹi, wɪtʃ i muvd əmʌŋ faɪv ɪndɪpɛndən bænz ʌv ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ faɪɾɝz sɪməlɝ tə ðɪs wʌn. hi weɪvd ɪz mɛn bæk ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ waɪl ɪz skaʊts bɹɔɾ ɪm ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ivən wɪð ðə skaʊts, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə ɡɛɾ ə ɡʊd ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi. hi hæd veɪɡ aɪdiəz ʌv wɛɹ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɹɪzɪstəns wɑz, ən sɛnt wʌɾ ɔɹɾɝz i kʊd, bʌt ðə bæɾəl wɑz spɹɛɾ oʊvɝ tu lɑɹdʒ ən ɛɹiə fəɹ ɪm tə bi eɪbəl tə koʊɔɹɾəneɪt ðə faɪɾɪŋ ɪfɛktɪvli. hi hoʊp joʊli wɑz wɛl.

His men finished off the fist of Trollocs, then hastened to another pre-decided building that they could hide in. Ituralde had about thirty archers and a company of cavalry, which he moved among five independent bands of irregular fighters similar to this one. He waved his men back into hiding while his scouts brought him information. Even with the scouts, it was difficult to get a good read on the large city. He had vague ideas of where the strongest resistance was, and sent what orders he could, but the battle was spread over too large an area for him to be able to coordinate the fighting effectively. He hoped Yoeli was well.

ði æʃəmən wɝ ɡɔn, ɪskeɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝ θɹu ðə taɪni ɡeɪtweɪ-oʊnli lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə kɹɔl θɹu - ðəɾ ænteɪl hæd meɪd. sɪns ðeɪd ɡɔn - ɪt wɑz aʊɝz əɡoʊ naʊ - ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ saɪn ʌv wʌtɛvɝ "ɹɛskjuɝz" wɝ səpoʊzədli kʌmɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ ði æʃəmən lɛft, hid sɛn ə skaʊt θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ðət ɹɪdʒ wɛɹ ðə læstʃɹaɪɾɝz hæd bɪn sɛd tə wɑtʃ. ɔl ðət ðə skaʊt faʊnd wɑz ən ɛmpti kæmp, ðə faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ ənətɛndɪd.

The Ashaman were gone, escaping at his order through the tiny gateway-only large enough to crawl through - that Antail had made. Since they'd gone - it was hours ago now - there had been no sign of whatever "rescuers" were supposedly coming. Before the Ashaman left, he'd sent a scout through a gateway to that ridge where the Lastriders had been said to watch. All that the scout found was an empty camp, the fire burning unattended.

ɪɾɝɑldi dʒɔɪn ɪz mɛn ɪnsaɪd ðə nu haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs, livɪŋ ɪz hæŋkɝtʃɪf - naʊ steɪnd wɪð sʊt - ɑn ðə duɹknɑb tə ɡɪv ðə skaʊts ə klu tə hɪz loʊkeɪʃən. wʌns ɪnsaɪd, hi fɹoʊz, hɪɹɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ aʊtsaɪd.

Ituralde joined his men inside the new hiding place, leaving his handkerchief - now stained with soot - on the doorknob to give the scouts a clue to his location. Once inside, he froze, hearing something outside.

"hʌʃ," hi sɛd tə ðə mɛn. ðeɪ stɪl ðɛɹ klɪŋkɪŋ ɑɹmɝ.

"Hush," he said to the men. They stilled their clinking armor.

fʊtfɔlz. mɛni ʌv ðɛm. ðət wɑz ə tʃɹɑlɑk bæn fəɹ sɝɾən; hɪz mɛn hæɾ ɔɹɾɝz tə muv saɪlənli. hi nɑɾəd tə hɪz soʊlʒɝz, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp sɪks fɪŋɡɝz. plæn nʌmbɝ sɪks. ðeɪd haɪd, weɪɾɪŋ, hoʊpɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝz wəd pæs əm baɪ. ɪf ðeɪ dɪdnt - ɪf ðeɪ dɪleɪd, əɹ stɑɹɾəd sɝtʃɪŋ ðə nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋz - hɪz tim wəd bɝst aʊɾ ən bɹɔdsaɪd ðɛm.

Footfalls. Many of them. That was a Trolloc band for certain; his men had orders to move silently. He nodded to his soldiers, holding up six fingers. Plan number six. They'd hide, waiting, hoping the creatures would pass them by. If they didn't - if they delayed, or started searching the nearby buildings - his team would burst out and broadside them.

ɪt wɑz ðə ɹɪskiəst ə ðə plænz. hɪz mɛn wɝ ɪɡzɔstəɾ ən ðə kævəlɹi hæd bɪn sɛn tə ənʌðɝ ə hɪz ɡɹup ə dɪfɛndɝz. bʌt bɛɾɝ tə ətæk ðən bi dɪskʌvɝɾ əɹ sɝaʊndəd.

It was the riskiest of the plans. His men were exhausted and the cavalry had been sent to another of his group of defenders. But better to attack than be discovered or surrounded.

ɪɾɝɑldi saɪɾəld ʌp tə ðə wɪndoʊ, weɪɾɪŋ, lɪsnɪŋ, bɹiðɪŋ ʃæl-loʊli. laɪt, bʌɾ i wɑz taɪɝd.

Ituralde sidled up to the window, waiting, listening, breathing shal-lowly. Light, but he was tired.

ðə ɡɹup mɑɹtʃt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ aʊtsaɪd, fʊtfɔlz ɪn junəsən. ðət wɑz ɑd. tʃɹɑləks dɪdn mɑɹtʃ soʊ ɹɛɡjəlɝli.

The group marched around the corner outside, footfalls in unison. That was odd. Trollocs didn't march so regularly.

"maɪ lɔɹd," wʌn ə hɪz mɛn wɪspɝd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹən ɛni hʊvz."

"My Lord," one of his men whispered. "There aren't any hooves."

ɪɾɝɑldi fɹoʊz. ðə mæn wɑz ɹaɪt. hɪz taɪɹədnəs wɑz meɪkɪŋ ɪm stupəd. ðæts ən ɑɹmi ʌv hʌnʒɹədz, hi θɔt. hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, kɑfɪŋ dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, ən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. hi stɛpt aʊtsaɪd.

Ituralde froze. The man was right. His tiredness was making him stupid. That's an army of hundreds, he thought. He got to his feet, coughing despite himself, and pushed open the door. He stepped outside.

ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn blu daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ɪɾɝɑldi ɛs mɛn paɪld aʊt bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðə wɪn klɪɹd ðə smoʊk fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ tʃɹup ʌv ɪnfəntʃɹi kɪɾɪd aʊɾ ɪn sɪlvɝi ɑɹmɝ ən kæɹiɪŋ paɪks.

A gust of wind blew down the street as Ituralde s men piled out behind him. The wind cleared the smoke for a moment, revealing a large troop of infantry kitted out in silvery armor and carrying pikes.

ðeɪ simd ɡoʊsts fəɹ ə moʊmənt - ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ə fæntəm ɡoʊldən laɪt fɹəm əbʌv, ə sʌn i hæd nɑt sin ɪn mʌnθs.

They seemed ghosts for a moment - glowing in a phantom golden light from above, a sun he had not seen in months.

ðə nukʌmɝz bɪɡæn tə kɔl əz ðeɪ sɔ hɪm ən ɪz mɛn, ən tu ʌv ðɛɹ ɔfəsɝz tʃɑɹdʒd ʌp tə hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ sɑldəiən. "wɛɹ ɪz jəɹ kəmændɝ?" wʌn æskt. "ðə mæn ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi?"

The newcomers began to call as they saw him and his men, and two of their officers charged up to him. They were Saldaean. "Where is your commander?" one asked. "The man Rodel Ituralde?"

"aɪ. . ." ɪɾɝɑldi faʊn hɪmsɛlf kɑfɪŋ. "aɪ æm hi. hu ɑɹ ju?"

"I. . ." Ituralde found himself coughing. "I am he. Who are you?"

"blɛs ðə laɪt," wʌn ə ðə mɛn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ði ʌðɝz. "pæs ðə wɝd tə lɔɹd bæʃɪɹ!

"Bless the Light," one of the men said, turning back to the others. "Pass the word to Lord Bashere!

wiv faʊn hɪm!"

We've found him!"

ɪɾɝɑldi blɪŋkt. hi lʊk bæk əɾ ɪz fɪlθi mɛn, feɪsəz blækənd wɪð sʊt. mɔɹ ðən ə fju hæɾ ən ɑɹm ɪn ə slɪŋ. hid stɑɹɾəd wɪð tu hʌnʒɹəd. naʊ ðəɹ wɝ fɪfti. ðeɪ ʃəd bi sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ, bʌt moʊst ə fɛm sæt daʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kloʊzɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz.

Ituralde blinked. He looked back at his filthy men, faces blackened with soot. More than a few had an arm in a sling. He'd started with two hundred. Now there were fifty. They should be celebrating, but most of fhem sat down on the ground, closing their eyes.

ɪɾɝɑldi faʊn hɪmsɛlf læfɪŋ. "naʊ? ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛnz hɛlp naʊ?" hi stʌmbəld, ðən sæt daʊn, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə bɝnɪŋ skaɪ. hi wɑz læf-ɪŋ, ən i kəd nɑt stɑp. sun tɪɹz bɪɡæn stʃɹikɪŋ daʊn ɪz tʃiks.

Ituralde found himself laughing. "Now? The Dragon sends help now?" He stumbled, then sat down, staring up at the burning sky. He was laugh-ing, and he could not stop. Soon tears began streaking down his cheeks.

jɛs, ðəɹ wɑz sʌnlaɪɾ ʌp ðɛɹ.

Yes, there was sunlight up there.

ɪɾɝɑldi hæd ɹiɡeɪn səm kəmpoʊʒɝ baɪ ðə taɪm ðə tʃɹups lɛɾ ɪm ɪndə ə wɛl-dɪfɛndəd sɛktɝ ə ðə sɪɾi. ðə smoʊk hɪɹ wɑz mʌtʃ lɛs θɪk. səpoʊzədli, ælθɹz tʃɹups - lɛd baɪ dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ - hæd ɹikleɪmd moʊst ə mɛɹədɑn. wʌt wɑz lɛft ʌv ɪt. ðeɪd bɪn pʊɾɪŋ aʊt ðə faɪɝz.

Ituralde had regained some composure by the time the troops led him into a well-defended sector of the city. The smoke here was much less thick. Supposedly, alThor's troops - led by Davram Bashere - had reclaimed most of Maradon. What was left of it. They'd been putting out the fires.

ɪt wɑz soʊ ɑd tə si tʃɹups wɪð ʃaɪni ɑɹmɝ, nit junəfɔɹmz, klin feɪsəz. ðeɪd swɛpt ɪn wɪð lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ʌv æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ən ɑɹmi ðət - fəɹ naʊ - hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaɪv ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn bæk tə ðə hɪlsaɪd fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz əbʌv ðə ɹɪvɝ. ælθɹz mɛn lɛɾ ɪm tə ə tɔl bɪldɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. wɪð ðə pæləs bɝn aʊt, moʊsli dɪstʃɹɔɪd, ɪt lʊk laɪk ðeɪd pɪk ðɪs bɪldɪŋ əz ə kəmæn sɛntɝ.

It was so odd to see troops with shiny armor, neat uniforms, clean faces. They'd swept in with large numbers of Asha'man and Aes Sedai, and an army that - for now - had been enough to drive the Shadowspawn back to the hillside fortifications above the river. Al'Thor's men led him to a tall building inside the city. With the palace burned out, mostly destroyed, it looked like they'd picked this building as a command center.

ɪɾɝɑldi hæd bɪn faɪɾɪŋ ə dʒɹeɪnɪŋ wɔɹ fəɹ wiks naʊ. ælθɹz tʃɹups simd ɔlmoʊs tu klin. hɪz mɛn hæd bɪn daɪɪŋ waɪl ðiz mɛn wɑʃt ən slɛpt ən daɪn ɑn hɑt fud?

Ituralde had been fighting a draining war for weeks now. Al'Thor's troops seemed almost too clean. His men had been dying while these men washed and slept and dined on hot food?

stɑp ɪt, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf, ɛntɝɪŋ ðə bɪldɪŋ. ɪt wɑz fɑɹ tu izi tə bleɪm ʌðɝz wən ə bæɾəl wɛn ɹɔŋ. ɪt wɑzn ðə fɔlt ə ðiz mɛn ðət ðɛɹ laɪvz hæd bɪn iziɝ ðən ɪz ɹisənli.

Stop it, he told himself, entering the building. It was far too easy to blame others when a battle went wrong. It wasn't the fault of these men that their lives had been easier than his recently.

hi leɪbɝɾ ʌp ðə stɛɹz, wɪʃɪŋ ðeɪd lɛɾ ɪm bi. ə ɡʊd naɪts slip, ə wɑʃ, ən ðən i kəd mit wɪð bæʃɪɹ. bʌt noʊ, ðət wʊdn du. ðə bæɾəl wɑzn oʊvɝ, ən ælθɹz mɛn wəd niɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðəɾ ɪz maɪnd wɑz feɪlɪŋ hɪm, wɝkɪŋ vɛɹi sloʊli.

He labored up the stairs, wishing they'd let him be. A good night's sleep, a wash, and then he could meet with Bashere. But no, that wouldn't do. The battle wasn't over, and al'Thor's men would need information. It was just that his mind was failing him, working very slowly.

hi ɹitʃt ðə tɑp flɔɹ ən fɑloʊd bæʃɪɹz soʊlʒɝz ɪndə ə ɹum tə ðə ɹaɪt. bæʃɪɹ stʊd ðɛɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ə bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt wɪθaʊt ðə mætʃɪŋ hɛlmət, hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əz i lʊkt aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ. hi wɔɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz oʊvɝli lɑɹdʒ sɑldəiən mʌstæʃɪz ən ə pɛɹ ʌv ɑləv tʃɹaʊzɝz stʌft ɪndə ni-haɪ buts.

He reached the top floor and followed Bashere's soldiers into a room to the right. Bashere stood there, wearing a burnished breastplate without the matching helmet, hands clasped behind his back as he looked out the window. He wore one of those overly large Saldaean mustaches and a pair of olive trousers stuffed into knee-high boots.

bæʃɪɹ tɝn ən stɑɹɾəd. "laɪt! jə lʊk laɪk dɛθ ɪtsɛlf, mæn!" hi tɝn tə ðə soʊlʒɝz.

Bashere turned and started. "Light! You look like death itself, man!" He turned to the soldiers.

"hi ʃəd bi ɪn ðə hilɝz tɛnt! sʌmwʌn fɛtʃ ən æʃəmən!"

"He should be in the Healer's tent! Someone fetch an Asha'man!"

'ɪm ɔl ɹaɪt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, fɔɹsɪŋ stɝnnəs ɪndə hɪz vɔɪs. "aɪ lʊk wɝs ðən aɪ fil, aɪd wɔɹənt."

'I'm all right," Ituralde said, forcing sternness into his voice. "I look worse than I feel, I'd warrant."

ðə soʊlʒɝz hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ tə bæʃɪɹ. "wɛl," ðə mæn sɛd, "æt list ɡɛɾ ɪm ə tʃɛɹ ən sʌmθɪŋ tə waɪp ɪz feɪs wɪð. jə pʊɹ fɛloʊ; wi ʃʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ deɪz əɡoʊ."

The soldiers hesitated, looking to Bashere. "Well," the man said, "at least get him a chair and something to wipe his face with. You poor fellow; we should have been here days ago."

aʊtsaɪd, ɪɾɝɑldi kəd hɪɹ ðə saʊnz ə dɪstən bæɾəl. bæʃɪɹ hæd tʃoʊzən ə tɔl bɪldɪŋ, wʌn fɹəm wɪtʃ i kəd sɝveɪ ðə faɪɾɪŋ. ðə soʊlʒɝz bɹɔɾ ə tʃɛɹ, ən - fəɹ ɔl ɪz wɪʃ tə ʃoʊ ə stʃɹɔŋ feɪs tə ə fɛloʊ dʒɛnɝəl - ɪɾɝɑldi sæt wɪð ə saɪ.

Outside, Ituralde could hear the sounds of distant battle. Bashere had chosen a tall building, one from which he could survey the fighting. The soldiers brought a chair, and - for all his wish to show a strong face to a fellow general - Ituralde sat with a sigh.

hi lʊk daʊn, ən wɑz əmeɪz tə si haʊ dɝɾi hɪz hænz wɝ əz ðoʊ hid bɪn klinɪŋ ə hɑɹθ. noʊ daʊɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz sʊt-kʌvɝd, stʃɹikt wɪð swɛt, ən ðəɹ wɑz laɪkli stɪl dʒɹaɪd blʌɾ ɑn ɪt. hɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz ɹæɡəd fɹəm ðə blæs ðət hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə wɔl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə heɪstəli bændədʒ kʌɾ ɑn ɪz ɑɹm.

He looked down, and was amazed to see how dirty his hands were as though he'd been cleaning a hearth. No doubt his face was soot-covered, streaked with sweat, and there was likely still dried blood on it. His clothing was ragged from the blast that had destroyed the wall, not to mention a hastily bandaged cut on his arm.

"jɔɹ dɪfɛns ə ðɪs sɪɾi wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə stʌnɪŋ, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɔɹmæləɾi tə hɪz toʊn - sɑldɑiə ən ɑɹæd dumən wɝ nɑɾ ɛnəmiz, bʌt tu stʃɹɔŋ neɪʃənz kəd nɑt ʃɛɹ ə bɔɹɾɝ wɪθaʊt pɪɹiədz ʌv ænəmɑsəɾi. "ðə nʌmbɝ ə tʃɹɑləks dɛd kəmpɛɹd tə ðə nʌmbɝ ə mɛn jə hæd . . . ən wɪð ə ɡæp ðət lɑɹdʒ ɪn ðə wɔl . . . lemi seɪ ðəɾ aɪm ɪmpɹɛst." bæʃɪɹz toʊn ɪmplaɪd ðət sətʃ pɹeɪz wɑz nɑɾ izəli ɡɪvən.

"Your defense of this city was nothing short of stunning, Lord Ituralde," Bashere said. There was a formality to his tone - Saldaea and Arad Doman were not enemies, but two strong nations could not share a border without periods of animosity. "The number of Trollocs dead compared to the number of men you had . . . and with a gap that large in the wall . . . Let me say that I'm impressed." Bashere's tone implied that such praise was not easily given.

"wʌɾ ə joʊli?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt.

"What of Yoeli?" Ituralde asked.

bæʃɪɹz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu ɡɹɪm. "maɪ mɛn faʊn ə smɔl bæn dɪfɛndɪŋ ɪz kɔɹps. hi daɪd bɹeɪvli, ðoʊ aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɪm ɪn kəmæn ən tɔɹkjəmɛn - ə dɪstən kʌzən ə maɪn, ðə pɹəzum liɾɝ ə ðə sɪɾi - lɑkt ɪn ɪz ɹumz, ən əbændənd, wɛɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks cʊɾə ɡɑɾən hɪm."

Bashere's expression grew grim. "My men found a small band defending his corpse. He died bravely, though I was surprised to find him in command and Torkumen - a distant cousin of mine, the presumed leader of the city - locked in his rooms, and abandoned, where the Trollocs could have gotten him."

"joʊli wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd stɪfli. "əmʌŋ ðə bɹeɪvəst aɪv hæd ði ɑnɝ ə noʊɪŋ.

"Yoeli was a good man," Ituralde said stiffly. "Among the bravest I've had the honor of knowing.

hi seɪv maɪ laɪf, bɹɔt maɪ mɛn ɪndə ðə sɪɾi əɡɛns tɔɹkjəmɛnz ɔɹɾɝz. ɪts ə bɝnɪŋ ʃeɪm tə luz hɪm. ə bɝnɪŋ ʃeɪm. wɪθaʊt joʊli, mɛɹədɑn wʊdn stæn ɹaɪt naʊ."

He saved my life, brought my men into the city against Torkumen's orders. It's a burning shame to lose him. A burning shame. Without Yoeli, Maradon wouldn't stand right now."

"ɪt hɑɹdli stænz ɛniweɪ," bæʃɪɹ sɛd sɑmbɝli.

"It hardly stands anyway," Bashere said somberly.

ɪɾɝɑldi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hiz ʌŋkəl tə ðə kwin - ðɪs sɪɾi ɪz pɹɑbli hɪz hoʊm.

Ituralde hesitated. He's uncle to the Queen - this city is probably his home.

ðə tu lʊkt ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, laɪk oʊld wʊlvz, liɾɝz ə ɹaɪvəl pæks. stɛpɪŋ sɔfli. "aɪm sɑɹi fəɹ jəɹ lɔs," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

The two looked at one another, like old wolves, leaders of rival packs. Stepping softly. "I'm sorry for your loss," Ituralde said.

"ðə sɪɾi stænz əz wɛl əz ɪt dʌz," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, "bɪkɔz ə ju. aɪm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi, mæn. aɪm sæɾənd, bʌt nɑɾ æŋɡɹi. ən əl teɪk jəɹ wɝɾ ɑn joʊli. tə bi fɹæŋk, aɪv nɛvɝ laɪk tɔɹkjəmɛn.

"The city stands as well as it does," Bashere said, "because of you. I'm not angry, man. I'm saddened, but not angry. And I'll take your word on Yoeli. To be frank, I've never liked Torkumen.

fəɹ naʊ, aɪv lɛft ɪm ɪn ðə ɹum wɛɹ wi faʊn ɪm - stɪl əlaɪv, θæŋkfəli - ðoʊ əl hɪɹ θʌndɝ fɹəm ðə kwin fəɹ wʌts bɪn dʌn tə hɪm. ʃiz ɔlweɪz bɪn fɑn ə hɪm. bɑ! ʃi nɔɹməli hæz bɛɾɝ dʒʌdʒmənt."

For now, I've left him in the room where we found him - still alive, thankfully - though I'll hear thunder from the Queen for what's been done to him. She's always been fond of him. Bah! She normally has better judgment."

bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd tə ðə saɪd wən i spoʊk ə tɔɹkjəmɛn, ən - wɪð ə stɑɹt - ɪɾɝɑldi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs bɪldɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz tɔɹku- mɛnz hoʊm, wɛɹ joʊli hæd bɹɔɾ ɪɾɝɑldi ɑn ɪz fɝs deɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ɪt meɪd sɛns tə tʃuz ðɪs bɪldɪŋ əz ə kəmæn poʊst - ɪt wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ðə nɔɹðɝn wɔl tə hæv ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ði aʊtsaɪd, bʌt fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ fɹəm ðə blæs tə hæv sɝvaɪvd, ənlaɪk ðə kaʊnsəl hɔl.

Bashere nodded to the side when he spoke of Torkumen, and - with a start - Ituralde realized that he recognized this building. This was Torku- men's home, where Yoeli had brought Ituralde on his first day in the city. It made sense to choose this building as a command post - it was close enough to the northern wall to have a good view of the outside, but far enough away from the blast to have survived, unlike the Council Hall.

wɛl, ɪt wʊɾə sɝv tɔɹkjəmɛn ɹaɪɾ ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd ɡɑɾən hɪm. ɪɾɝɑldi sæt bæk, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz, əz bæʃɪɹ kənsʌltəd wɪð ɪz ɔfəsɝz. bæʃɪɹ wɑz keɪpəbəl, ðət mʌtʃ wɑz ɑbviəs. vɛɹi kwɪkli hid swɛp ðə sɪɾi klin; wʌns ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd ɹilaɪz ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə lɑɹdʒɝ fɔɹs tə faɪt, ðeɪɾ əbændən ðə sɪɾi. ɪɾɝɑldi kəd fil pɹaɪd ðæt, ɪn pɑɹt, hɪz tənæsɪɾi wɑz wʌt hæd meɪɾ əm soʊ kwɪk tə ɹʌn.

Well, it would have served Torkumen right if the Trollocs had gotten him. Ituralde sat back, closing his eyes, as Bashere consulted with his officers. Bashere was capable, that much was obvious. Very quickly he'd swept the city clean; once the Trollocs had realized that there was a larger force to fight, they'd abandoned the city. Ituralde could feel pride that, in part, his tenacity was what had made them so quick to run.

ɪɾɝɑldi kəntɪnjud tə lɪsən. moʊst ə bæʃɪɹz tʃɹups hæd kʌm ɪndə ðə sɪɾi θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz, æftɝ sɛndɪŋ ɪn wʌn skaʊt tə faɪn seɪf pleɪsəz tə meɪk ðɛm. faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits wʊdnt wɝk fəɹ ɪm əz ɪt hæɾ ɪɾɝɑldi; ðə hɪt-ænd-haɪd tæktɪk hæd bɪn dɪvoʊɾəd tə duɪŋ əz mʌtʃ dæmədʒ əz pɑsəbəl bɪfɔɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ kɪld. ɪt wɑz ə luzɪŋ tæktɪk.

Ituralde continued to listen. Most of Bashere's troops had come into the city through gateways, after sending in one scout to find safe places to make them. Fighting in the streets wouldn't work for him as it had Ituralde; the hit-and-hide tactic had been devoted to doing as much damage as possible before getting killed. It was a losing tactic.

ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd pʊl bæk ɪndə ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdn steɪ ðəɹ fəɹ lɔŋ. əz i sæt wɪð kloʊzd aɪz, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə steɪ əweɪk, ɪɾɝɑldi hɝd bæʃɪɹ ən ɪz kæptənz kʌm tə ðə seɪm daɪɹ kənkluʒən ɪɾɝɑldi hæd. mɛɹədɑn wɑz lɔst. ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn wəd weɪt fəɹ naɪt, ðən swɔɹm ɪn əɡɛn.

The Trollocs had pulled back into the fortifications, but they wouldn't stay there for long. As he sat with closed eyes, struggling to stay awake, Ituralde heard Bashere and his captains come to the same dire conclusion Ituralde had. Maradon was lost.
