The Shadowspawn would wait for night, then swarm in again.

æftɝ ɔl ðɪs, ðeɪd dʒʌs fli? æftɝ joʊli hæd daɪd hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɪɾi? æftɝ ɹədʒɑbi hæd bɪn kɪl baɪ ə dʒɹæɡkɝ? æftɝ æŋkɑɹ ən ɹɑsɪn hæd fɔlən dʊɹɪŋ ðə skɝmɪʃɪz ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz? æftɝ ɔl ðə blʌdʃɛd, ðeɪ faɪnəli sɔ hɛlp ɝaɪv, oʊnli tə hæv ɪt pɹuv ɪnsəfɪʃənt?

After all this, they'd just flee? After Yoeli had died holding the city? After Rajabi had been killed by a Draghkar? After Ankaer and Rossin had fallen during the skirmishes inside the walls? After all the bloodshed, they finally saw help arrive, only to have it prove insufficient?

"pɝhæps wi kəd pʊʃ əm ɔf ðət hɪltɑp," wʌn ə bæʃɪɹz mɛn sɛd. "klin aʊt ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz."

"Perhaps we could push them off that hilltop," one of Bashere's men said. "Clean out the fortifications."

hi dɪdn saʊn vɛɹi ɑptəmɪstɪk.

He didn't sound very optimistic.

"sʌn," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪz aɪz oʊpən, "aɪ hɛl ðət hɪl fəɹ wiks əɡɛnst ə supɪɹiɝ fɔɹs.

"Son," Ituralde said, forcing his eyes open, "I held that hill for weeks against a superior force.

jəɹ pipəl bɪlt ɪɾ ʌp wɛl, ən ðə pɹɑbləm wɪð wɛl-bɪl fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz ɪz ðət jəɹ ɛnəmi kən tɝn əm əɡɛns ju. jəl luz mɛn ətækɪŋ ðɛɹ. ə lɑɾ ə ðɛm."

Your people built it up well, and the problem with well-built fortifications is that your enemy can turn them against you. You'll lose men attacking there. A lot of them."

ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlənt. wi liv, ðɛn," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "nf, wɪl nid ɡeɪtweɪz."

The room fell silent. We leave, then," Bashere said. "Naeff, we'll need gateways."

'jɛs, lɔɹd bæʃɪɹ." skwɛɹ-feɪst ən lin ə bɪld, ðə mæn wɔɹ ðə blæk koʊɾ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən pɪn ʌv ən æʃəmən.

'Yes, Lord Bashere." Square-faced and lean of build, the man wore the black coat and the Dragon pin of an Asha'man.

məleɪn, ɡæðɝ ðə kævəlɹi ən ɔɹɡənaɪz əm aʊtsaɪd; meɪk ɪt lʊk əz ɪf wɝ gɑnə tʃɹaɪ ən əsɔlt əɡɛns ðɛɹ fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz. ðæɾəl kip əm iɡɝ ən weɪɾɪŋ. wɪl ɪvækjəeɪt ðə wundəd, ðən wɪl əv ðə kævəlɹi tʃɑɹdʒ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən ɪndə - "

Malain, gather the cavalry and organize them outside; make it look as if we're going to try an assault against their fortifications. That'll keep them eager and waiting. We'll evacuate the wounded, then we'll have the cavalry charge in the other direction into - "

"baɪ ðə laɪɾ ən maɪ hoʊp fəɹ ɹibɝθ!" ə vɔɪs sʌɾənli ɪkskleɪmd.

"By the Light and my hope for rebirth!" a voice suddenly exclaimed.

ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə ɹum tɝn ɪn ʃɑk; ðət wɑzn ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv oʊθ jə hɝɾ ɛvɹi deɪ.

Everyone in the room turned in shock; that wasn't the sort of oath you heard every day.

ə jʌŋ soʊlʒɝ stʊd baɪ ðə wɪndoʊ, lʊkɪŋ aʊt wɪð ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. bæʃɪɹ kɝst, ən hɝid tə ðə wɪndoʊ, ði ʌðɝz kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊnd, sɛvɹəl teɪkɪŋ aʊt lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz.

A young soldier stood by the window, looking out with a looking glass. Bashere cursed, and hurried to the window, the others crowding around, several taking out looking glasses.

wʌt naʊ? ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt, stændɪŋ dɪspaɪɾ ɪz fətiɡ ən hɝiɪŋ oʊvɝ. wʌt kəd ðeɪ pɑsəbli hæv kʌm ʌp wɪð? mɔɹ dʒɹæɡkɝ? dɑɹkhaʊnz?

What now? Ituralde thought, standing despite his fatigue and hurrying over. What could they possibly have come up with? More Draghkar? Darkhounds?

hi pɪɹɾ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ, ən sʌmwʌn hændəɾ ɪm ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. hi ɹeɪzd ɪt, ən əz hid ɡɛst, ðə bɪldɪŋ wɑz ɑn ɪnʌf ʌv ə ɹaɪz tə ' lʊk aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi wɔl ən ɑntu ðə kɪlɪŋ fild aʊtsaɪɾ ən ðə bɪɑnd. ðə taʊɝ pəzɪʃənz ɑn ðə kɹɛst ə ðə hɪl wɝ klʌstɝd wɪð ɹɑ-' vɛnz.

He peered out the window, and someone handed him a looking glass. He raised it, and as he'd guessed, the building was on enough of a rise to ' look out over the city wall and onto the killing field outside and the beyond. The tower positions on the crest of the hill were clustered with ra-' vens.

θɹu ðə ɡlæs, hi kəd si tʃɹɑləks klɑɡɪŋ ðə haɪts, hoʊldɪŋ ði ʌpɝ kæmp, ðə taʊɝz, ən ðə bəlwɹks ðɛɹ.

Through the glass, he could see Trollocs clogging the heights, holding the upper camp, the towers, and the bulwarks there.

bɪɑn ðə hɪl, sɝdʒɪŋ daʊn θɹu ðə pæs, wɑz ən ɑsəm fɔɹs ə tʃɹɑləks, mɛni taɪmz ðə nʌmbɝ ðət hæɾ əsɔltɪd mɛɹədɑn. ðə weɪv ə mɑnstɝz sim tə kəntɪnju ɑn fɝɛvɝ, "wi nid tə ɡoʊ," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. "ɪmiɾiətli."

Beyond the hill, surging down through the pass, was an awesome force of Trollocs, many times the number that had assaulted Maradon. The wave of monsters seemed to continue on forever, "We need to go," Bashere said, lowering his looking glass. "Immediately."

"laɪt!" ɪɾɝɑldi wɪspɝd. "ɪf ðət fɔɹs ɡɛts pæst ʌs, ðəɹ woʊn bi ɛniθɪŋ ɪn sɑldɑiə, ændɝ, əɹ ɑɹæd dumən ðət kən stɑp ɪt. pliz tɛl mi ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən meɪd pis wɪð ðə sintʃæn, əz i pɹɑməst?"

"Light!" Ituralde whispered. "If that force gets past us, there won't be anything in Saldaea, Andor, or Arad Doman that can stop it. Please tell me the Lord Dragon made peace with the Seanchan, as he promised?"

"ɪn ðæt," ə kwaɪət vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, "æz ɪn soʊ mɛni ʌðɝ θɪŋz, aɪ hæv feɪld."

"In that," a quiet voice said from behind, "as in so many other things, I have failed."

ɪɾɝɑldi spʌn, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. ə tɔl mæn wɪð ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum - ə mæn hum ɪɾɝɑldi fɛlt i hæd nɛvɝ mɛt bɪfɔɹ, dɪspaɪt ðə fəmɪljɝ fitʃɝz.

Ituralde spun, lowering his looking glass. A tall man with reddish hair stepped into the room - a man whom Ituralde felt he had never met before, despite the familiar features.

ɹænd ælθɹ hæd tʃeɪnʒd.

Rand al'Thor had changed.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd ðət seɪm sɛlf-kɑnfəɾəns, ðət seɪm stʃɹeɪt bæk, ðət seɪm æɾətud ɪkspɛktɪŋ oʊbiɾiəns. ən jɛt, ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim dɪfɹənt. ðə weɪ hi stʊd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ feɪnli səspɪʃəs. ðə weɪ hi stʌɾid ɪɾɝɑldi wɪð kənsɝn.

The Dragon Reborn had that same self-confidence, that same straight back, that same attitude expecting obedience. And yet, at the same time, everything seemed different. The way he stood, no longer faintly suspicious. The way he studied Ituralde with concern.

ðoʊz aɪz, koʊld ən ɪmoʊʃənləs, hæd wʌns kənvɪnst ɪɾɝɑldi tə fɑloʊ ðɪs mæn. ðoʊz aɪz hæd tʃeɪnʒd, tu. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd nɑt noʊɾəd wɪzdəm ɪn əm bɪfɔɹ.

Those eyes, cold and emotionless, had once convinced Ituralde to follow this man. Those eyes had changed, too. Ituralde had not noted wisdom in them before.

doʊn bi ə θɪkhɛɾɪd ful, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt, jə kæn tɛl ɪf ə mæn ɪz waɪz baɪ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz aɪz.

Don't be a thickheaded fool, Ituralde thought, you can't tell if a man is wise by looking at his eyes.

ən jɛɾ i kʊd.

And yet he could.

"ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi," ælθɹ sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ən leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪɾɝɑldi ɛs ɑɹm. "aɪ lɛf jə ən jəɹ mɛn stʃɹændəɾ ən oʊvɝwɛlmd. pliz fɝɡɪv mi."

"Rodel Ituralde," al'Thor said, stepping forward and laying a hand on Ituralde s arm. "I left you and your men stranded and overwhelmed. Please forgive me."

"aɪ meɪd ðɪs tʃɔɪs maɪsɛlf," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. ɑdli, hi fɛlt lɛs taɪɝd ðən i hæd dʒʌs moʊməns əɡoʊ.

"I made this choice myself," Ituralde said. Oddly, he felt less tired than he had just moments ago.

"aɪ hæv ɪnspɛktɪd jəɹ mɛn," ælθɹ sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ soʊ fju lɛft, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ bɹoʊkən ən bæɾɝd. haʊ dɪd jə hoʊl ðɪs sɪɾi? wʌt juv dʌn ɪz ə mɪɹəkəl."

"I have inspected your men," al'Thor said. "There are so few left, and they are broken and battered. How did you hold this city? What you have done is a miracle."

"aɪ də wʌt nidz tə bi dʌn."

"I do what needs to be done."

"ju mʌst əv lɔs mɛni fɹɛnz."

"You must have lost many friends."

"aɪ. . . jɛs." wʌɾ ʌðɝ ænsɝ wɑz ðɛɹ? tə dɪsmɪs ɪɾ əz nʌθɪŋ wəd bi tə dɪsɑnɝ ðɛm.

"I. . . Yes." What other answer was there? To dismiss it as nothing would be to dishonor them.

"weɪkeɪɾə fɛl tədeɪ. ɹədʒɑbi . . . wɛl, ə dʒɹæ-kɑɹ ɡɑt hɪm. æŋkɑɹ. hi læstəɾ əntɪl ðɪs æftɝnun.

"Wakeda fell today. Rajabi . . . well, a Dragh-kar got him. Ankaer. He lasted until this afternoon.

nɛvɝ dɪd faɪn aʊt waɪ ðət tʃɹʌmpəɾɝ saʊndəɾ ɝli. ɹɑsɪn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ɪt. hiz dɛd, tu."

Never did find out why that trumpeter sounded early. Rossin was looking into it. He's dead, too."

"wi nid tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs ɝdʒənt. "aɪm sɑɹi, mæn. mɛɹədɑn ɪz lɔst."

"We need to get out of the city," Bashere said, his voice urgent. "I'm sorry, man. Maradon is lost."

"noʊ," ælθɹ sɛd sɔfli. "ðə ʃædoʊ wɪl nɑɾ əv ðɪs sɪɾi. nɑɾ æftɝ wʌt ðiz mɛn dɪd tə hoʊld ɪt. əl nɑɾ əlaʊ ɪt."

"No," al'Thor said softly. "The Shadow will not have this city. Not after what these men did to hold it. I will not allow it."

"æn ɑnɝəbəl sɛntəmənt," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, "bʌt wi doʊnt . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ælθɹ lʊkt ət hɪm.

"An honorable sentiment," Bashere said, "but we don't . . ." He trailed off as al'Thor looked at him.

ðoʊz aɪz. soʊ ɪntɛns. ðeɪ simd ɔlmoʊst əlaɪt. "ðeɪ wɪl nɑt teɪk ðɪs sɪɾi, bæʃɪɹ,"

Those eyes. So intense. They seemed almost alight. "They will not take this city, Bashere,"

ælθɹ sɛd, ən ɛdʒ ʌv æŋɡɝ ɛntɝɪŋ ɪz kwaɪət vɔɪs. hi weɪv tə ðə saɪd, ən ə ɡeɪtweɪ splɪt ði ɛɹ. ðə saʊnz ə dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹɑləks jɛlɪŋ ɡɹu kloʊsɝ, sʌɾənli. "aɪm taɪɝɾ ə lɛɾɪŋ ɪm hɝt maɪ pipəl. pʊl jəɹ soʊlʒɝz bæk."

al'Thor said, an edge of anger entering his quiet voice. He waved to the side, and a gateway split the air. The sounds of drums and Trollocs yelling grew closer, suddenly. "I'm tired of letting him hurt my people. Pull your soldiers back."

wɪð ðæt, ælθɹ stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ə pɛɹ ʌv il meɪɾənz hɝiɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum, ən i lɛf ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə lip θɹu bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðən i lɛɾ ɪt vænɪʃ.

With that, al'Thor stepped through the gateway. A pair of Aiel Maidens hurried into the room, and he left the gateway open long enough for them to leap through behind him. Then he let it vanish.

bæʃɪɹ lʊk stʌnd, maʊθ hæf-oʊpən. "kɝs ðət mæn!" hi faɪnəli sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə ðə wɪndoʊ əɡɛn. "aɪ θɔɾ i wɑzn gɑnə də ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ!"

Bashere looked stunned, mouth half-open. "Curse that man!" he finally said, turning to the window again. "I thought he wasn't going to do this sort of thing any longer!"

ɪɾɝɑldi dʒɔɪn bæʃɪɹ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, lʊkɪŋ aʊt θɹu ði ɪnɔɹməs ɡæp ɪn ðə wɔl. aʊtsaɪd, ælθɹ wɑz kɹɔsɪŋ ðə tʃɹæmpəld ɡɹaʊnd, wɛɹɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊn kloʊk ən fɑloʊd baɪ ðə tu meɪɾənz.

Ituralde joined Bashere, raising his looking glass, looking out through the enormous gap in the wall. Outside, al'Thor was crossing the trampled ground, wearing his brown cloak and followed by the two Maidens.

ɪɾɝɑldi θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ ðə saʊnz ə ðə haʊlɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. ðɛɹ dʒɹʌmz bit. ðeɪ sɔ θɹi pipəl əloʊn.

Ituralde thought he could hear the sounds of the howling Trollocs. Their drums beat. They saw three people alone.

ðə tʃɹɑləks sɝdʒ fɔɹwɝd, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hʌnʒɹədz, θaʊzənz. ɪɾɝɑldi ɡæspt.

The Trollocs surged forward, charging across the ground. Hundreds, Thousands. Ituralde gasped.

bæʃɪɹ ʌɾɝd ə kwaɪət pɹɛɹ.

Bashere uttered a quiet prayer.

ælθɹ ɹeɪzd wʌn hænd, ðən θɹʌst ɪt - pɑm fɔɹwɝd - təwɔɹd ðə taɪɾ ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn.

Al'Thor raised one hand, then thrust it - palm forward - toward the tide of Shadowspawn.

ən ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd tə daɪ.

And they started to die.

ɪt bɪɡæn wɪð weɪvz ə faɪɝ, mʌtʃ laɪk ðə wʌnz æʃəmən juzd. oʊnli ðiz wɝ fɑɹ lɑɹdʒɝ. ðə fleɪmz bɝn tɛɹəbəl swɑθs ə dɛθ θɹu ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ fɑloʊd ðə kɔɹs ə ðə lænd, sipɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪl ən daʊn ɪndə ðə tʃɹɛntʃɪz, fɪlɪŋ əm wɪð waɪt-hɑt faɪɝ, sɪɹɪŋ ən dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ.

It began with waves of fire, much like the ones Asha'man used. Only these were far larger. The flames burned terrible swaths of death through the Trollocs. They followed the course of the land, seeping up the hill and down into the trenches, filling them with white-hot fire, searing and destroying.

klaʊdz ə dʒɹæɡkɝ spʌn ɪn ðə skaɪ, daɪvɪŋ fəɹ ælθɹ. ði ɛɹ əbʌv ɪm tɝn blu, ən ʃɑɹdz ʌv aɪs ɪksploʊɾəd aʊtwɝd, spɹeɪɪŋ ði ɛɹ laɪk æɹoʊz fɹəm ðə baʊz ʌv ən ɪntaɪɝ bænɝ ʌv ɑɹtʃɝz.

Clouds of Draghkar spun in the sky, diving for al'Thor. The air above him turned blue, and shards of ice exploded outward, spraying the air like arrows from the bows of an entire banner of archers.

ðə bists ʃɹik ðɛɹ ɪnhjumən æɡəni, kɑɹkəsɪz tʌmbəlɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

The beasts shrieked their inhuman agony, carcasses tumbling to the ground.

laɪɾ ən paʊɝ ɪksploʊɾəd fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi wɑz laɪk ən ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi ʌv tʃænlɝz.

Light and Power exploded from the Dragon Reborn. He was like an entire army of channelers.

θaʊzənz ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn daɪd. dɛθɡeɪts spɹæŋ ʌp, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kɪlɪŋ hʌnʒɹədz.

Thousands of Shadowspawn died. Deathgates sprang up, striking across the ground, killing hundreds.

ði æʃəmən nf - stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd bæʃɪɹ - ɡæspt. "aɪv nɛvɝ sin soʊ mɛni wivz ət wʌns," hi wɪspɝd. "aɪ kæn tʃɹæk əm ɔl. hiz ə stɔɹm. ə stɔɹm ə laɪɾ ən stʃɹimz ə paʊɝ!"

The Asha'man Naeff - standing beside Bashere - gasped. "I've never seen so many weaves at once," he whispered. "I can't track them all. He's a storm. A storm of Light and streams of Power!"

klaʊdz bɪɡæn tə fɔɹm ən swɝl əbʌv ðə sɪɾi. ðə wɪn pɪkt ʌp, haʊlɪŋ, ən laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹʌk fɹəm əbʌv. blæsts ə θʌndɝ oʊvɝpaʊɝd ðə saʊnz ə dʒɹʌmz əz tʃɹɑləks tʃɹaɪɾ ɪn veɪn tə ɡɛt tə ælθɹ, klaɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə bɝnɪŋ kɑɹkəsɪz ə ðɛɹ bɹɛðɹən. ðə swɝlɪŋ waɪt klaʊdz kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə blæk, bɔɪlɪŋ tɛmpəst, ɪntɝmɪŋɡəlɪŋ. wɪn spʌn ɝaʊn ælθɹ, wɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz kloʊk.

Clouds began to form and swirl above the city. The wind picked up, howling, and lightning struck from above. Blasts of thunder overpowered the sounds of drums as Trollocs tried in vain to get to al'Thor, climbing over the burning carcasses of their brethren. The swirling white clouds crashed into the black, boiling tempest, intermingling. Wind spun around al'Thor, whipping at his cloak.

ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf sim tə bi ɡloʊɪŋ. wɑz ɪt ðə ɹəflɛkʃən ə ðə swɑθs ə faɪɝ, əɹ pɝhæps ðə laɪtnɪŋ blæsts? ælθɹ sim bɹaɪɾɝ ðən əm ɔl, hɪz hæn əpɹeɪzd əɡɛns ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn.

The man himself seemed to be glowing. Was it the reflection of the swaths of fire, or perhaps the lightning blasts? Al'Thor seemed brighter than them all, his hand upraised against the Shadowspawn.

hɪz meɪɾənz hʌntʃt nɪɹ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, aɪz fɔɹwɝd, ʃoʊldɝz sɛɾ əɡɛns ðə ɡɹeɪt wɪnd.

His Maidens hunched near the ground on either side of him, eyes forward, shoulders set against the great wind.

klaʊdz spɪnɪŋ əbaʊt wʌn ənʌðɝ meɪd fʌnəlz ɪndə ðə mæsəz ə tʃɹɑləks, swipɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ə ðə hɪl, teɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə kɹitʃɝz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ɡɹeɪt wɔɾɝspaʊts ɹoʊz bɪhaɪnd, meɪɾ ə flɛʃ ən faɪɝ. ðə bists ɹeɪn daʊn, fɔlɪŋ əpɑn ði ʌðɝz. ɪɾɝɑldi wɑtʃt wɪð ɑ, ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz ən hɛd ɹaɪzɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛnɝdʒi tə ðə vɛɹi ɛɹ ɪtsɛlf.

Clouds spinning about one another made funnels into the masses of Trollocs, sweeping across the top of the hill, taking up the creatures into the air. Great waterspouts rose behind, made of flesh and fire. The beasts rained down, falling upon the others. Ituralde watched with awe, the hair on his arms and head rising. There was an energy to the very air itself.

ə skɹim keɪm fɹəm nɪɹbaɪ. wɪðɪn ðə bɪldɪŋ, ɪn wʌn ə ðə nɪɹbaɪ ɹumz. ɪɾɝɑldi dɪd nɑt tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. hi hæd tə wɑtʃ ðɪs bjuɾəfəl, tɛɹəbəl moʊmən ə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ən paʊɝ.

A scream came from nearby. Within the building, in one of the nearby rooms. Ituralde did not turn away from the window. He had to watch this beautiful, terrible moment of destruction and Power.

weɪvz ə tʃɹɑləks bɹoʊk, ðə dʒɹʌmz fɔltɝɪŋ. ɪntaɪɝ lidʒənz ə ðɛm tɝn ən flɛd, stʌmbəlɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪlsaɪɾ ən oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ, fliɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə blaɪt. səm ɹɪmeɪn fɝm - tu æŋɡɹi, tu ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ðoʊz dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðɛm, əɹ tu stupəd tə fli. ðə tɛmpəst ə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən sim tə kʌm tə ə pik, flæʃɪz ə laɪt blæstɪŋ daʊn ɪn taɪm wɪð haʊlɪŋ wɪnd, θɹʌmɪŋ weɪvz ə bɝnɪŋ fleɪm, tɪŋkəlɪŋ ʃɑɹdz ʌv aɪs.

Waves of Trollocs broke, the drums faltering. Entire legions of them turned and fled, stumbling up the hillside and over one another, fleeing back toward the Blight. Some remained firm - too angry, too intimidated by those driving them, or too stupid to flee. The tempest of destruction seemed to come to a peak, flashes of light blasting down in time with howling wind, thrumming waves of burning flame, tinkling shards of ice.

ɪt wɑz ə mæstɝwɝk. ə tɛɹəbəl, dɪstʃɹʌktɪv, wʌndɝfəl mæstɝwɝk. ælθɹ lɪftəɾ ɪz hæn təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ. ðə wɪnz ɡɹu fæstɝ, ðə laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹaɪks lɑɹdʒɝ, ðə faɪɝz hɑɾɝ. tʃɹɑləks skɹimd, moʊnd, haʊld. ɪɾɝɑldi faʊn hɪmsɛlf tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ.

It was a masterwork. A terrible, destructive, wonderful masterwork. Al'Thor lifted his hand toward the sky. The winds grew faster, the lightning strikes larger, the fires hotter. Trollocs screamed, moaned, howled. Ituralde found himself trembling.

ælθɹ kloʊzd ɪz hæn ɪndə ə fɪst, ən ɪɾ ɔl ɛndəd.

Al'Thor closed his hand into a fist, and it all ended.

ðə læst ə ðə wɪnd-siz tʃɹɑləks dʒɹɑp fɹəm ðə skaɪ laɪk livz əbændən baɪ ə pæsɪŋ bɹiz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɛl saɪlənt. ðə fleɪmz daɪd, ðə blæk ən waɪt klaʊdz klɪɹɾ ən oʊpən tə ə blu skaɪ.

The last of the wind-seized Trollocs dropped from the sky like leaves abandoned by a passing breeze. Everything fell silent. The flames died, the black and white clouds cleared and opened to a blue sky.

ælθɹ loʊɝɾ ɪz hænd. ðə fil bɪfɔɹ ɪm wɑz paɪld wɪð kɑɹkəsɪz ətɑp kɑɹkəsɪz. tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ə dɛd tʃɹɑləks smoʊldɝɪŋ. dɝɛkli bɪfɔɹ ælθɹ, ə paɪl ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz waɪd fɔɹmd ə ɹɪdʒ faɪv fit tɔl ə maʊn ə dɛd ðət hæd nɪɹli ɹitʃt hɪm.

Al'Thor lowered his hand. The field before him was piled with carcasses atop carcasses. Tens of thousands of dead Trollocs smoldering. Directly before al'Thor, a pile a hundred paces wide formed a ridge five feet tall a mound of dead that had nearly reached him.

haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt teɪkən? ɪɾɝɑldi faʊn ðəɾ i kəd nɑt ɡeɪdʒ ðə taɪm, ðoʊ lʊkɪŋ ət ðə sʌn, ət list ən aʊɝ hæd pæst. pɝhæps mɔɹ. ɪt hæd sim laɪk sɛkənz.

How long had it taken? Ituralde found that he could not gauge the time, though looking at the sun, at least an hour had passed. Perhaps more. It had seemed like seconds.

ælθɹ tɝn tə wɔk əweɪ. ðə meɪɾənz ɹoʊz ɑn ʃeɪki fit, stʌmbəlɪŋ æftɝ hɪm.

Al'Thor turned to walk away. The Maidens rose on shaky feet, stumbling after him.

"wʌt wɑz ðət skɹim?" nf æskt. "ðə wʌn nɪɹbaɪ, ɪn ðə bɪldɪŋ. dɪd jə hɪɹ ɪt?"

"What was that scream?" Naeff asked. "The one nearby, in the building. Did you hear it?"

ɪɾɝɑldi fɹaʊnd. wʌt hæd ðət bɪn? hi kɹɔs ðə ɹum, ði ʌðɝz - ɪnkluɾɪŋ sɛvɹəl ə bæʃɪɹz ɔfəsɝz - fɑloʊɪŋ. mɛni ʌðɝz steɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹum, haʊɛvɝ, stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ət ðə fil ðət hæd bɪn klɛnz baɪ aɪs ən baɪ faɪɝ. ɪt wɑz ɑd, bʌɾ ɪɾɝɑldi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə spɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl fɔlən taʊɝ ətɑp ðə hɪl. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ælθɹz ətæks hæd sʌmhaʊ əfɛktəɾ oʊnli ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. kəɾ ə mæn ɹɪli bi ðət pɹɪsaɪs?

Ituralde frowned. What had that been? He crossed the room, the others - including several of Bashere's officers - following. Many others stayed in the room, however, staring out at the field that had been cleansed by ice and by fire. It was odd, but Ituralde hadn't been able to spot a single fallen tower atop the hill. It was as if al'Thor's attacks had somehow affected only the Shadowspawn. Could a man really be that precise?

ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd wɑz ɛmpti, bʌɾ ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ə səspɪʃən naʊ ʌv wɛɹ ðə skɹim hæd kʌm fɹʌm. hi wɔk tə lɔɹd tɔɹkjəmɛnz dɔɹ; bæʃɪɹ ənlɑkt ɪt, ən ðeɪ wɛn ɪnsaɪd.

The hallway outside was empty, but Ituralde had a suspicion now of where the scream had come from. He walked to Lord Torkumen's door; Bashere unlocked it, and they went inside.

ɪt simd ɛmpti. ɪɾɝɑldi fɛlt ə spaɪk ə fɪɹ. hæd ðə mæn ɪskeɪpt? hi pʊld aʊɾ ɪz sɔɹd.

It seemed empty. Ituralde felt a spike of fear. Had the man escaped? He pulled out his sword.

noʊ. ə fɪɡjɝ wɑz hʌɾəld ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd, faɪn kloʊðɪŋ ɹɪŋkəld, dʌbəlɛt steɪnd wɪð blʌd. ɪɾɝɑldi loʊɝɾ ɪz sɔɹd. lɔɹd tɔɹkjəmɛnz aɪz wɝ ɡɔn. hi əpɪɹd tə hæv pʊɾ əm aʊt wɪð ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ kwɪl; ðə blʌɾid ɪmpləmən leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm.

No. A figure was huddled in the corner beside the bed, fine clothing wrinkled, doublet stained with blood. Ituralde lowered his sword. Lord Torkumen's eyes were gone. He appeared to have put them out with a writing quill; the bloodied implement lay on the ground beside him.

ðə wɪndoʊ wɑz bɹoʊkən. bæʃɪɹ ɡlænst aʊɾ ɪt. "leɪɾi tɔɹkjəmɛn ɪz daʊn ðɛɹ."

The window was broken. Bashere glanced out it. "Lady Torkumen is down there."

"ʃi dʒʌmpt," tɔɹkjəmɛn wɪspɝd, klɔɪŋ əɾ ɪz aɪ sɑkəts, fɪŋɡɝz kʌvɝd wɪð blʌd. hi saʊndəd deɪzd. "ðæt laɪt . . . ðət tɛɹəbəl laɪt: ɪɾɝɑldi ɡlænst ət bæʃɪɹ. "aɪ kænɑt wɑtʃ ɪt,"

"She jumped," Torkumen whispered, clawing at his eye sockets, fingers covered with blood. He sounded dazed. "That light . . . That terrible light: Ituralde glanced at Bashere. "I cannot watch it,"

tɔɹkjəmɛn mʌɾɝd. "aɪ kænɑt! ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, wɛɹ ɪz jəɹ pɹətɛkʃən? wɛɹ ɑɹ jəɹ ɑɹmiz tə ɹɛnd, jəɹ sɔɹdz tə stʃɹaɪk? ðət laɪɾ its ət maɪ maɪnd, laɪk ɹæts fistɪŋ ɑn ə kɔɹps. ɪt bɝnz ət maɪ θɔts. ɪt kɪl mi. ðət laɪt kɪl mi."

Torkumen muttered. "I cannot! Great Lord, where is your protection? Where are your armies to rend, your swords to strike? That Light eats at my mind, like rats feasting on a corpse. It burns at my thoughts. It killed me. That light killed me."

"hiz ɡɔn mæd," bæʃɪɹ sɛd ɡɹɪmli, nilɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə mæn. "bɛɾɝ ðən i dɪzɝvd, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ðoʊz ɹæmbəlɪŋz. laɪt! maɪ oʊn kʌzən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. ən ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə sɪɾi!"

"He's gone mad," Bashere said grimly, kneeling down beside the man. "Better than he deserved, judging by those ramblings. Light! My own cousin a Darkfriend. And in control of the city!"

"wʌɾ ɪz i tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" wʌn ə bæʃɪɹz mɛn sɛd. "ə laɪt? ʃʊɹli hi kʊdn əv sin ðə bæɾəl. nʌn ə ðiz wɪndoʊz feɪs ðə ɹaɪt weɪ."

"What is he talking about?" one of Bashere's men said. "A light? Surely he couldn't have seen the battle. None of these windows face the right way."

"aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ i wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə bæɾəl, voʊɡəlɝ," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "kʌm ɑn. aɪ səspɛk ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪz gɑnə bi taɪɝd. aɪ wɑnə si ðət hiz kɛɹd fɔɹ."

"I'm not sure he was talking about the battle, Vogeler," Bashere said. "Come on. I suspect the Lord Dragon is going to be tired. I want to see that he's cared for."

ðɪs ɪz ɪt, mɪn θɔt, tæpɪŋ ðə peɪdʒ. ʃi sæɾ ɑn əɹ wɪndaʊsəl ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə bɹiz. tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk ə ɹænd. hi wɑzn hɝt, bʌɾ ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz wɝ soʊ stʃɹɔŋ. æŋɡɝ. ʃid hoʊpt i wʊdn bi soʊ æŋɡɹi ɛvɝ əɡɛn.

This is it, Min thought, tapping the page. She sat on her windowsill in the Stone of Tear, enjoying the breeze. Trying not to think of Rand. He wasn't hurt, but his emotions were so strong. Anger. She'd hoped he wouldn't be so angry ever again.

ʃi ʃʊk ɔf ðə wɝiɪŋ; ʃi hæd wɝk tə du. wɑz ʃi fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ɹɔŋ θɹɛd? wɑz ʃi ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ? ʃi ɹɛd ðə laɪn əɡɛn. laɪɾ ɪz hɛl bɪfɔɹ ðə mɔ ʌv ði ɪnfənət vɔɪd, ən ɔl ðət hiz kən bi sizd.

She shook off the worrying; she had work to do. Was she following the wrong thread? Was she interpreting in the wrong way? She read the line again. Light is held before the maw of the infinite void, and all that he is can be seized.

hɝ spɛkjəleɪʃən kʌɾ ɔf əz ʃi sɔ ə laɪɾ əpɪɹ fɹəm ðə ɹum əkɹɔs ðə hɔl. ʃi dʒɹɑpt əɹ bʊk ən lɛp daʊn tə ðə flɔɹ. ɹænd wɑz sʌɾənli kloʊs. ʃi kəd fil ɪt θɹu ðə bɑnd.

Her speculation cut off as she saw a light appear from the room across the hall. She dropped her book and leaped down to the floor. Rand was suddenly close. She could feel it through the bond.

tu meɪɾənz ɡɑɹɾəd ðə ɹum əkɹɔs ðə hɔl, moʊsli tə pɹɪvɛn pipəl fɹəm wɑndɝɪŋ ɪn ən ɡɛɾɪŋ hɝt baɪ ɡeɪtweɪz. ðə wʌn ðət hæɾ oʊpənd naʊ lɛd tə ə pleɪs ðət smɛld ə smoʊk. ɹænd stʌmbəl θɹu. mɪn ɹæn tə hɪm. hi lʊkt ɪɡzɔstəd, aɪz ɹɛd, feɪs wɑn. hi lin əɡɛnst əɹ wɪð ə saɪ, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ hɛlp ɪm tə ə tʃɛɹ.

Two Maidens guarded the room across the hall, mostly to prevent people from wandering in and getting hurt by gateways. The one that had opened now led to a place that smelled of smoke. Rand stumbled through. Min ran to him. He looked exhausted, eyes red, face wan. He leaned against her with a sigh, letting her help him to a chair.

"wʌt hæpənd?" mɪn dɪmændəɾ ʌv ɪvæsni, ðə meɪɾən u keɪm θɹu nɛkst. ʃi wɑz ə læŋki wʊmən wɪð dɑɹk ɹɛd hɛɹ, kʌt ʃɔɹt wɪð ə teɪl ɪn ðə bæk laɪk ðəɾ ə moʊs meɪɾənz.

"What happened?" Min demanded of Evasni, the Maiden who came through next. She was a lanky woman with dark red hair, cut short with a tail in the back like that of most Maidens.

"ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz wɛl," ðə wʊmən sɛd. "ðoʊ hiz laɪk ə juθ u ɹæn wʌn mɔɹ læp ɝaʊn ðə kæmp ðən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, oʊnli tə pɹuv ðəɾ i kʊd."

"The Car'a'carn is well," the woman said. "Though he is like a youth who ran one more lap around the camp than everyone else, only to prove that he could."

"hi ɡeɪn mʌtʃ dʒi tədeɪ," aɪfeɪinə - ði ʌðɝ meɪɾən - sɛd, ɔlmoʊst ɪn ɑɹɡjəmənt. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz sɑləm.

"He gained much ji today," Ifeyina - the other Maiden - said, almost in argument. Her voice was solemn.

ɹænd saɪd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ. bæʃɪɹ fɑloʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, buts hɪɾɪŋ stoʊn.

Rand sighed, settling back in the chair. Bashere followed out of the gateway, boots hitting stone.

mɪn hɝd kɔlz fɹəm daʊn bɪloʊ - ə ɡɹup ʌv wundəd soʊlʒɝz biɪŋ bɹɔt θɹu ə lɑɹdʒɝ ɡeɪtweɪ. ðə stoʊnz kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz wɝ əlaɪv wɪð æktɪvəɾi, ɛɛs sədaɪ hilɝz ɹʌnɪŋ tə kɛɹ fəɹ ðə blʌɾid, suɾi mɛn.

Min heard calls from down below - a group of wounded soldiers being brought through a larger gateway. The Stone's courtyards were alive with activity, Aes Sedai Healers running to care for the bloodied, sooty men.

æftɝ bæʃɪɹ keɪm ə lin dəmɑni mæn ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz. ɹoʊɾəl ɪtʃɹɑldi. hi lʊk mʌtʃ ðə wɝs fəɹ wɛɹ, wɪð dʒɹaɪd blʌɾ ɑn ɪz fɪlθi feɪs ɪz kloʊðɪŋ ɹɪpt, ən bɛɹɪŋ ə klʌmzi bændɪdʒ ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. ɹænd hæd noʊ vɪzəbəl wunz. hɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz klin, ðoʊ hi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn stɪl wɛɹɪŋ ðəɾ eɪdʒ bɹaʊn kloʊk. bʌt laɪt, hi lʊk taɪɝd.

After Bashere came a lean Domani man in his middle years. Rodel Iturralde. He looked much the worse for wear, with dried blood on his filthy face his clothing ripped, and bearing a clumsy bandage on his arm. Rand had no visible wounds. His clothing was clean, though he insisted on still wearing that aged brown cloak. But Light, he looked tired.

"ɹænd," mɪn sɛd, nilɪŋ daʊn. "ɹænd, ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"Rand," Min said, kneeling down. "Rand, are you all right?"

"aɪ ɡɹu æŋɡɹi," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ hæd θɔt maɪsɛlf bɪɑn ðæt."

"I grew angry," Rand said softly. "I had thought myself beyond that."

ʃi fɛlt ə tʃɪl.

She felt a chill.

"ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə tɛɹəbəl æŋɡɝ, laɪk bɪfɔɹ," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪt wɑz nɑt ði æŋɡɝ ə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən, ðoʊ aɪ dɪd dɪstʃɹɔɪ. ɪn mɛɹədɑn, aɪ sɔ wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn tə mɛn u fɑloʊd mi. aɪ sɔ laɪɾ ɪn ðɛm, mɪn. dɪfaɪɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn noʊ mæɾɝ ðə lɛŋθ ə hɪz ʃædoʊ. wɪl lɪv, ðət dɪfaɪəns sɛd. wɪl lʌv ən wɪl hoʊp.

"It was not a terrible anger, like before," Rand said. "It was not the anger of destruction, though I did destroy. In Maradon, I saw what had been done to men who followed me. I saw Light in them, Min. Defying the Dark One no matter the length of his shadow. We will live, that defiance said. We will love and we will hope.

"æn aɪ sɔ hɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðæt. hi noʊz ðəɾ ɪf i kəd bɹeɪk ðɛm, ɪt wəd min sʌmθɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən mɛɹədɑn. bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə spɪɹəɾ ə mɛn ... hi θɝsts fəɹ ðæt.

"And I saw him trying so hard to destroy that. He knows that if he could break them, it would mean something. Something much more than Maradon. Breaking the spirit of men ... he thirsts for that.

hi stʃɹʌk fɑɹ hɑɹɾɝ ðən i ʌðɝwaɪz wəɾ əv kəz i wɑntəd tə bɹeɪk maɪ spɪɹət." hɪz vɔɪs ɡɹu sɑftɝ ən i oʊpən ɪz aɪz, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ. "æn soʊ aɪ stʊɾ əɡɛns hɪm."

He struck far harder than he otherwise would have because he wanted to break my spirit." His voice grew softer and he opened his eyes, looking down at her. "And so I stood against him."

"wʌt jə dɪd wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd mɪn wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəd. "bʌt dɪd jə lɛɾ ɪm dʒɹaɪv jə tə ɪt?"

"What you did was amazing," Bashere said, standing beside Min with his arms folded. "But did you let him drive you to it?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ hæv ə ɹaɪt tə maɪ æŋɡɝ, bæʃɪɹ. doʊn jə si? bɪfɔɹ, aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊld ɪɾ ɔl hɪɾən wɪðɪn. ðət wɑz ɹɔŋ. aɪ mʌs fil. aɪ mʌs hɝt fəɹ ðə peɪnz, ðə dɛθs, ðə lɔsəz ə ðiz pipəl. aɪ hæv tə klɪŋ tə ðiz θɪŋz soʊ aɪ noʊ waɪ aɪm faɪɾɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ taɪmz wən aɪ nid ðə vɔɪd, bʌt ðət dʌz nɑt meɪk maɪ æŋɡɝ ɛni lɛs ə pɑɹɾ ə mi."

Rand shook his head. "I have a right to my anger, Bashere. Don't you see? Before, I tried to hold it all hidden within. That was wrong. I must feel. I must hurt for the pains, the deaths, the losses of these people. I have to cling to these things so I know why I am fighting. There are times when I need the void, but that does not make my anger any less a part of me."

hi sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt wɪð itʃ wɝd, ən mɪn nɑɾəd.

He seemed to be growing more confident with each word, and Min nodded.

"wɛl, jə seɪv ðə sɪɾi," bæʃɪɹ sɛd.

"Well, you saved the city," Bashere said.

"nɑt sun ɪnʌf," ɹænd sɛd. mɪn kəd fil ɪz sɑɹoʊ. "æn maɪ ækʃənz tədeɪ meɪ stɪl əv bɪn ə mɪsteɪk."

"Not soon enough," Rand said. Min could feel his sorrow. "And my actions today may still have been a mistake."

mɪn fɹaʊnd. "waɪ?"

Min frowned. "Why?"

ɪt keɪm tu kloʊs tə ə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən bɪtwin ʌs," ɹænd sɛd. "ðæt mʌs hæpən ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, ən ət ðə ɹaɪt taɪm. aɪ kænɑɾ əfɔɹd tə lɛɾ ɪm pɹəvoʊk mi. bæʃɪɹ ɪz ɹaɪt. nɔɹ kən aɪ əfɔɹd tə lɛt ðə mɛn əsum ðəɾ əl ɔlweɪz bi eɪbəl tə stɛp ɪn ən seɪv ðɛm."

It came too close to a confrontation between us," Rand said. "That must happen at Shayol Ghul, and at the right time. I cannot afford to let him provoke me. Bashere is right. Nor can I afford to let the men assume that I will always be able to step in and save them."

pɝhæps," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "bʌt wʌt jə dɪd tədeɪ . . ."

Perhaps," Bashere said. "But what you did today . . ."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ æm nɑt tə faɪt ðɪs wɔɹ, bæʃɪɹ. tədeɪz bæɾəl ɪɡzɔstəd mi bɪɑnd wʌɾ aɪ ʃəɾ əv əlaʊd. ɪf maɪ ɛnəmiz wɝ tə kʌm əpɑn mi naʊ, aɪd bi fɪnɪʃt. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ kən oʊnli faɪɾ ɪn wʌn pleɪs əɾ ə taɪm. wʌɾ ɪz kʌmɪŋ wɪl bi ɡɹændɝ ðən ðæt, ɡɹændɝ ən mɔɹ tɛɹəbəl ðən ɛni wʌn mæn kəd hoʊp tə hoʊl bæk. əl ɔɹɡənaɪz ju, bʌɾ aɪ mʌs liv ju. ðə wɔɹ wɪl bi jʊɹz."

Rand shook his head. "I am not to fight this war, Bashere. Today's battle exhausted me beyond what I should have allowed. If my enemies were to come upon me now, I'd be finished. Besides, I can only fight in one place at a time. What is coming will be grander than that, grander and more terrible than any one man could hope to hold back. I will organize you, but I must leave you. The war will be yours."

hi fɛl saɪlənt, ən flɪn stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, lɛɾɪŋ ɪt slɪd kloʊzd.

He fell silent, and Flinn stepped through the gateway, letting it slid closed.

"aɪ mʌst ɹɛs naʊ," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "təmɑɹoʊ aɪ mit wɪð jəɹ nis ən ði ʌðɝ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, bæʃɪɹ. aɪ noʊ nɑt wʌt ðəl ɹikwaɪɝ ə mi, bʌt ðeɪ mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ poʊsts. ɪf sɑldɑiə wɑz ɪn sətʃ ə steɪt wɪð wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt kæptənz liɾɪŋ ðə dɪfɛns, aɪ kən oʊnli ɡɛs wʌt ði ʌðɝ bɔɹɾɝlənd neɪʃənz ɑɹ sʌfɝɪŋ."

"I must rest now," Rand said softly. "Tomorrow I meet with your niece and the other Borderlanders, Bashere. I know not what they will require of me, but they must return to their posts. If Saldaea was in such a state with one of the great captains leading the defense, I can only guess what the other Borderland nations are suffering."

mɪn hɛlpt ɪm tə hɪz fit. "ɹænd," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "kædzueɪn ɹɪtɝnd, ən ʃi hæd sʌmwʌn wɪð hɝ."

Min helped him to his feet. "Rand," she said softly. "Cadsuane returned, and she had someone with her."

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "teɪk mi tə hɝ."

He hesitated. "Take me to her."

mɪn wɪnst. "aɪ ʃʊdn əv mɛnʃən ɪt. jə ʃəd ɹɛst."

Min winced. "I shouldn't have mentioned it. You should rest."

"aɪ wɪl," hi sɛd. "doʊnt wɝi."

"I will," he said. "Don't worry."

ʃi kəd stɪl sɛns ɪz ɪɡzɔstʃən. bʌt ʃi dɪdn ɑɹɡju. ðeɪ wɔk fɹəm ðə ɹum. "ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi," ɹænd sɛd, pɔzɪŋ baɪ ðə dɔɹweɪ. "ju wɪl wɪʃ tə əkʌmpəni mi. aɪ kænɑt ɹipeɪ jə fəɹ ði ɑnɝ juv ʃoʊn, bʌɾ aɪ də hæv sʌmθɪŋ aɪ kən ɡɪv."

She could still sense his exhaustion. But she didn't argue. They walked from the room. "Rodel Ituralde," Rand said, pausing by the doorway. "You will wish to accompany me. I cannot repay you for the honor you have shown, but I do have something I can give."

ðə ɡɹɪzəl dəmɑni nɑɾəd, fɑloʊɪŋ. mɪn hɛlpt ɹænd daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm. dɪɾ i hæv tə pʊʃ hɪmsɛlf ðɪs hɑɹd?

The grizzled Domani nodded, following. Min helped Rand down the corridor, worrying about him. Did he have to push himself this hard?

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hi dʌz. ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hid bi blɛd dʒɹaɪ, ɡɹaʊn daʊn, juzd ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðɪs wɑz θɹu. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə wʊmən stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ.

Unfortunately, he does. Rand al'Thor was the Dragon Reborn. He'd be bled dry, ground down, used up before this was through. It was almost enough to make a woman stop trying.

"ɹænd . . ." ʃi sɛd, ɪɾɝɑldi ən sɛvɹəl meɪɾənz tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ðɛm. fɔɹtʃənətli, kædzueɪn ɛs ɹum wɑzn fɑɹ.

"Rand . . ." she said, Ituralde and several Maidens trailing them. Fortunately, Cadsuane s room wasn't far.

"aɪ wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd. "aɪ pɹɑməs. hæv jə nuz ə jəɹ stʌɾiz?" hi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪstʃɹæk hɝ.

"I will be all right," he said. "I promise. Have you news of your studies?" He was trying to distract her.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðət kwɛstʃən dʒʌst sɛn əɹ tə ənʌðɝ wɝi. "hæv jə ɛvɝ wʌndɝd waɪ keɪlændɝ ɪz soʊ ɔfən kɔld ə 'fɪɹfəl bleɪd' əɹ 'ðə bleɪɾ ə ɹuən' ɪn ðə pɹɑfəsiz?"

Unfortunately, that question just sent her to another worry. "Have you ever wondered why Cailandor is so often called a 'fearful blade' or 'the blade of ruin' in the prophecies?"

"ɪts sətʃ ə paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil," hi sɛd. "meɪbi ɪts kəz ə ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ɪt kən kɑz?"

"It's such a powerful sa'angreal," he said. "Maybe it's because of the destruction it can cause?"

"meɪbi," ʃi sɛd.

"Maybe," she said.

"ju θɪŋk ɪts sʌmθɪŋ ɛls."

"You think it's something else."

"ðɛɹz ə fɹeɪz," mɪn sɛd, "ɪn ðə dʒɛndaɪ pɹɑfəsi. aɪ wɪʃ wi nu mɔɹ ə ðɛm. ɛniweɪ, ɪt sɛz 'æn ðə bleɪd wɪl baɪn ɪm baɪ tweɪn.''

"There's a phrase," Min said, "in the Jendai Prophecy. I wish we knew more of them. Anyway, it says 'and the Blade will bind him by twain.''

"tu wɪmən," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ nid tə bi ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð tu wɪmən tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt."

"Two women," Rand said. "I need to be in a circle with two women to control it."

ʃi ɡɹɪməst.

She grimaced.

"wʌt?" ɹænd sɛd. "ju maɪɾ əz wɛl bi aʊt wɪð ɪt, mɪn. aɪ nid tə noʊ.

"What?" Rand said. "You might as well be out with it, Min. I need to know.

"ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ fɹeɪz, fɹəm ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl. ɛniweɪ, aɪ θɪŋk hæt kælændɝ maɪt bi flɔd bɪɑn ðæt. aɪ θɪŋk ɪt maɪt . . . ɹænd, aɪ θɪŋk ɪt maɪt meɪk jə wik, oʊpən jə tə ətæk, ɪf jə juz ɪt."

"There's another phrase, from The Karaethon Cycle. Anyway, I think hat Callandor might be flawed beyond that. I think it might . . . Rand, I think it might make you weak, open you to attack, if you use it."

"pɝhæps ðæts haʊ əl bi kɪld, ðɛn."

"Perhaps that's how I'll be killed, then."

"ju ɑɹən gɑnə bi kɪld," mɪn sɛd.

"You aren't going to be killed," Min said.

"aɪ - "

"I - "

"jul lɪv θɹu ðɪs, ʃifɝɾɝ," ʃi ɪnsɪstəd. "aɪm gɑnə si ðət jə du."

"You'll live through this, sheepherder," she insisted. "I'm going to see that you do."

hi smaɪld ət hɝ. hi lʊk soʊ taɪɝd. "aɪ ɔlmoʊs bɪliv ðət jəl də ɪt, mɪn. pɝhæps aɪm nɑt ðə wʌn ðə pæɾɝn bɛnz ɝaʊnd, bʌt ju." hi tɝnd, ðən nɑkt ɑn ə dɔɹ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ.

He smiled at her. He looked so tired. "I almost believe that you'll do it, Min. Perhaps I'm not the one the Pattern bends around, but you." He turned, then knocked on a door in the hallway.

ɪt kɹækt, mɛɹaɪs pikɪŋ aʊt. ʃi lʊkt ɹænd ʌp ən daʊn. "ju sim əz ɪf jə kən bɛɹli stæn ɑn jəɹ oʊn fit, ælθɹ."

It cracked, Merise peeking out. She looked Rand up and down. "You seem as if you can barely stand on your own feet, al'Thor."

"tʃɹu ɪndid," hi ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪz kædzueɪn sədaɪ hɪɹ?"

"True indeed," he replied. "Is Cadsuane Sedai here?"

"ʃi hæz dʌn əz jə æskt," mɛɹaɪs ɹɪplaɪd. "ænd, aɪ maɪt seɪ, ʃiz bɪn vɛɹi əkɑmədeɪɾɪŋ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ jə - "

"She has done as you asked," Merise replied. "And, I might say, she's been very accommodating, considering how you - "

aɪ ə ədmɪt juv ə væləd kənsɝn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɛvɝ sɪns aɪ lɛt maɪsɛlf ɡɛt kæptʃɝd baɪ ɪleɪɾ eɪz kɹoʊniz aʊtsaɪɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, aɪv wʌndɝɾ ɪf aɪ bɪkʌm tu dɝɛkli ɪnvɑlvd, tu dɝɛkli ɪn deɪnʒɝ."

I a admit you have a valid concern," Egwene said. "Ever since I let myself get captured by Elaid a's cronies outside of Tar Valon, I've wondered if I become too directly involved, too directly in danger."

"ɪɡzækli," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"Exactly," Nynaeve said.

"haʊɛvɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ðə sɪmpəl fækt ɹɪmeɪnz ðəɾ aɪm ðə wʌn əmʌŋ əs u ɪz moʊst ɛkspɝɾ ət tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. jə tu ɑɹ skɪld, tʃɹu, bʌɾ aɪ hæv mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns. ɪn ðɪs keɪs, aɪm nɑt dʒʌs ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪm ə tul ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ mʌs juz." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd "aɪ dʒɹim ðɪs, nɪneɪiv. ɪf wi də nɑt dɪfit mɛsænə hɪɹ, ɔl kəd bi lɔst. ɔl wɪl bi lɔst. ɪts nɑɾ ə taɪm tə hoʊl bæk ɛni ʌv əɹ tulz, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ væljəbəl."

"However," Egwene said, "the simple fact remains that I am the one among us who is most expert at Tel'aran'rhiod. You two are skilled, true, but I have more experience. In this case, I am not just the leader of the Aes Sedai, I am a tool that the White Tower must use." She hesitated "I dreamed this, Nynaeve. If we do not defeat Mesaana here, all could be lost. All will be lost. It is not a time to hold back any of our tools, no matter how valuable."

nɪneɪiv ɹitʃt fəɹ əɹ bɹeɪd, bʌɾ ɪt naʊ keɪm oʊnli tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ ət ðæt.

Nynaeve reached for her braid, but it now came only to her shoulders She gritted her teeth at that.

"ju maɪɾ əv ə pɔɪnt. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt."

"You might have a point. But I don't like it."

"ði il dʒɹimwɔkɝz," sɪuən sɛd. "mʌðɝ, jə sɛd jəl bi mit-ɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. maɪt ðeɪ bi wɪlɪŋ tə hɛlp? aɪd fil mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ əbaʊt hævɪŋ jə faɪɾ ɪf aɪ nu ðeɪ wɝ ɝaʊn tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ju."

"The Aiel dreamwalkers," Siuan said. "Mother, you said you'll be meet-ing with them. Might they be willing to help? I'd feel much better about having you fight if I knew they were around to keep an eye on you."

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ə ɡʊd sədʒɛstʃən. əl kɑntækt əm bɪfɔɹ wi miɾ ən meɪk ðə ɹɪkwɛst, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs."

"Yes," Egwene said. "A good suggestion. I will contact them before we meet and make the request, just in case."

"mʌðɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "pɝhæps ɹænd - "

"Mother," Nynaeve said. "Perhaps Rand - "

"ðɪs ɪz ə mæɾɝ ə ðə taʊɝ, nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wi wɪl mænədʒ ɪt."

"This is a matter of the Tower, Nynaeve," Egwene said. "We will manage it."

"vɛɹi wɛl."

"Very well."

"naʊ," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud, "wi nid tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə spɹɛd ðə ɹaɪt ɹumɝz soʊ ðət mɛsænə woʊn bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪzɪs kʌmɪŋ tə lɪsən . . ."

"Now," Egwene continued, "we need to figure out how to spread the right rumors so that Mesaana won't be able to resist coming to listen . . ."

pɛɹɪn hɪt ðə naɪtmɛɹ ɹʌnɪŋ. ði ɛɹ bɛn ɝaʊn hɪm, ən ðə sɪɾi haʊzɪz - ðɪs taɪm ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn flæt-tɑp vɝaɪəɾi - dɪsəpɪɹd. ðə ɹoʊd bɪkeɪm sɑf bɪniθ ɪz fit, laɪk mʌd, ðən tɝn tə lɪkwəd.

Perrin hit the nightmare running. The air bent around him, and the city houses - this time of the Cairhienin flat-topped variety - disappeared. The road became soft beneath his feet, like mud, then turned to liquid.

hi splæʃt ɪn ði oʊʃən. wɔɾɝ əɡɛn? hi θɔt wɪð ənɔɪəns.

He splashed in the ocean. Water again? he thought with annoyance.

dip ɹɛd laɪtnɪŋ kɹæʃt ɪn ðə skaɪ, θɹoʊɪŋ weɪvz ə blʌɾi laɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə si. itʃ bɝst ɹɪvild ʃæɾoʊd kɹitʃɝz lɝkɪŋ bɪniθ ðə weɪvz. mæsɪv θɪŋz, ivəl ən sɪnwəs ɪn ðə spæzəmɪŋ ɹɛd laɪtnɪŋ.

Deep red lightning crashed in the sky, throwing waves of bloody light across the sea. Each burst revealed shadowed creatures lurking beneath the waves. Massive things, evil and sinuous in the spasming red lightning.

pipəl klʌŋ tə ðə ɹɛkədʒ ʌv wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ə ʃɪp, skɹimɪŋ ɪn tɛɹɝ ən kɹaɪɪŋ aʊt fəɹ lʌvd wʌnz. mɛn ɑn bɹoʊkən bɔɹdz, wɪmən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊl ðɛɹ beɪbiz əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ əz taʊɝɪŋ weɪvz bɹoʊk oʊvɝ ðɛm, dɛd bɑɾiz bɑbɪŋ laɪk sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn.

People clung to the wreckage of what had once been a ship, screaming in terror and crying out for loved ones. Men on broken boards, women trying to hold their babies above the water as towering waves broke over them, dead bodies bobbing like sacks of grain.

ðə θɪŋz bɪniθ ðə weɪvz stʃɹʌk, snætʃɪŋ pipəl fɹəm ðə sɝfəs ən dʒɹæɡɪŋ əm ɪndə ðə dɛpθs wɪð splæʃəz ə fɪnz ən spɑɹkɪŋ, ɹeɪzɝ-ʃɑɹp tiθ. ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz sun bʌbəlɪŋ ɹɛd ðət dɪdn kʌm fɹəm ðə laɪtnɪŋ.

The things beneath the waves struck, snatching people from the surface and dragging them into the depths with splashes of fins and sparking, razor-sharp teeth. The water was soon bubbling red that didn't come from the lightning.

huɛvɝ hæd dʒɹim ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ naɪtmɛɹ hæɾ ə sɪŋɡjəlɝli twɪstəɾ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən.

Whoever had dreamed this particular nightmare had a singularly twisted imagination.

pɛɹɪn ɹəfjuz tə lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi dʒɹɔn ɪn. hi skwɛltʃt ɪz fɪɹ, ən dɪd nɑt swɪm fəɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz plæŋks. ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil. ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil. ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil.

Perrin refused to let himself be drawn in. He squelched his fear, and did not swim for one of those planks. It isn't real. It isn't real. It isn't real.

dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ʌndɝstændɪŋ, pɑɹɾ ə hɪm nu ðəɾ i wɑz gɑnə daɪ ɪn ðiz wɔɾɝz. ðiz tɛɹəbəl, blʌɾi wɔɾɝz. ðə moʊnz ə ði ʌðɝz əsɔltɪd hɪm, ən i jɝn tə tʃɹaɪ tə hɛlp ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝn ɹil, hi nu. dʒʌs fɪɡməns. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd.

Despite his understanding, part of him knew that he was going to die in these waters. These terrible, bloody waters. The moans of the others assaulted him, and he yearned to try to help them. They weren't real, he knew. Just figments. But it was hard.

pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz fɹəm ðə wɔɾɝ, ðə weɪvz tɝnɪŋ bæk ɪndə ɡɹaʊnd. bʌt ðən i kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ əz sʌmθɪŋ bɹʌʃt ɪz lɛɡ. laɪtnɪŋ kɹæʃt bɹeɪkɪŋ ði ɛɹ. ə wʊmən bɪsaɪɾ ɪm slɪp bɪniθ ðə weɪvz, tʌɡd baɪ ənsin dʒɔz. pænɪkt, pɛɹɪn wɑz sʌɾənli bæk ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ, ðəɹ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ə kəmplitli dɪfɹən pleɪs, wʌn ɑɹm slʌŋ oʊvɝ ə pis ə ɹɛkədʒ.

Perrin began to rise from the water, the waves turning back into ground. But then he cried out as something brushed his leg. Lightning crashed breaking the air. A woman beside him slipped beneath the waves, tugged by unseen jaws. Panicked, Perrin was suddenly back in the water, there in a heartbeat, floating in a completely different place, one arm slung over a piece of wreckage.

ðɪs hæpən səmtaɪmz. ɪf i weɪvɝd fəɹ ə moʊmənt - ɪf i lɛt hɪmsɛlf si ðə naɪtmɛɹ əz ɹil  - ɪt wəd pʊl ɪm ɪn ən æktʃəli  muv hɪm, fɪɾɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ɪts tɛɹəbəl moʊzeɪɪk. sʌmθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ nɪɹbaɪ, ən i splæʃt əweɪ wɪð ə stɑɹt. wʌn ə ðə sɝdʒɪŋ weɪvz ɹeɪzd ɪm ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

This happened sometimes. If he wavered for a moment - if he let himself see the nightmare as real  - it would pull him in and actually move him, fitting him into its terrible mosaic. Something moved in the water nearby, and he splashed away with a start. One of the surging waves raised him into the air.

ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil. ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil. ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil.

It isn't real. It isn't real. It isn't real.

ðə wɔɾɝz wɝ soʊ koʊld. sʌmθɪŋ tʌtʃt ɪz lɛɡ əɡɛn, ən i skɹimd, ðən tʃoʊkt ɔf əz i ɡʌlpt ɪn ə maʊθfʊl ə sɔlti wɔɾɝ.

The waters were so cold. Something touched his leg again, and he screamed, then choked off as he gulped in a mouthful of salty water.

ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil/ hi wɑz ɪn kɛɹhin, liɡz fɹəm ði oʊʃən. ðɪs wɑz ə stʃɹit. hɑɹd stoʊnz bɪniθ. ðə smɛl ə beɪk bɹɛd kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ beɪkɝi. ðə stʃɹit laɪnd wɪð smɔl, θɪn-tʃɹʌŋkt æʃ tʃɹiz.

IT ISN'T REAL/ He was in Cairhien, leagues from the ocean. This was a street. Hard stones beneath. The smell of baked bread coming from a nearby bakery. The street lined with small, thin-trunked ash trees.

wɪð ə bɛloʊɪŋ skɹim, hi klʌŋ tə ðɪs nɑlədʒ əz ðə pipəl ɝaʊn ɪm hɛl tə ðɛɹ flɑtsəm. pɛɹɪn nɑɾɪd ɪz hænz ɪndə fɪsts, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ɹiæləɾi.

With a bellowing scream, he clung to this knowledge as the people around him held to their flotsam. Perrin knotted his hands into fists, focusing on reality.

ðəɹ wɝ kɑbəlstoʊnz ʌndɝ ɪz fit. nɑt weɪvz. nɑt wɔɾɝ. nɑt tiθ ən fɪnz. sloʊli, hi ɹoʊz fɹəm ði oʊʃən əɡɛn. hi stɛpt aʊɾ ʌv ɪɾ ən sɛɾ ɪz fʊɾ ɑn ðə sɝfəs, filɪŋ sɑləd stoʊn bɪniθ ɪz but. ði ʌðɝ fʊt fɑloʊd. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɑn ə smɔl, floʊɾɪŋ sɝkəl ə stoʊnz.

There were cobblestones under his feet. Not waves. Not water. Not teeth and fins. Slowly, he rose from the ocean again. He stepped out of it and set his foot on the surface, feeling solid stone beneath his boot. The other foot followed. He found himself on a small, floating circle of stones.

sʌmθɪŋ ɪnɔɹməs sɝdʒ fɹəm ðə wɔɾɝz tə hɪz lɛft, ə mæsɪv bis pɑɹt fɪʃ ən pɑɹt mɑnstɝ, wɪð ə mɔ soʊ waɪd ðəɾ ə mæn kəd wɔk ɪndə ɪt stændɪŋ əpɹaɪt. θɛtiθ wɝ əz lɑɹdʒ əz pɛɹɪnz hænd, ən ðeɪ ɡlɪɾɝd, dʒɹɪpɪŋ blʌd.

Something enormous surged from the waters to his left, a massive beast part fish and part monster, with a maw so wide that a man could walk into it standing upright. The'teeth were as large as Perrin's hand, and they glittered, dripping blood.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹil.

It was not real.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ɪksploʊɾəd ɪndə mɪst. ðə spɹeɪ hɪt pɛɹɪn, ðən dʒɹaɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli. ɝaʊn hɪm, ðə naɪtmɛɹ bɛnt, ə bʌbəl ə ɹiæləɾi pɹɛsɪŋ aʊt fɹəm hɪm. dɑɹk ɛɹ, koʊld weɪvz, skɹimɪŋ pipəl ɹæn təɡɛðɝ laɪk wɛt peɪnt.

The creature exploded into mist. The spray hit Perrin, then dried immediately. Around him, the nightmare bent, a bubble of reality pressing out from him. Dark air, cold waves, screaming people ran together like wet paint.

nɪɹ wɑz noʊ laɪtnɪŋ - hi dɪd nɑt si ɪt laɪɾ ɪz aɪlɪdz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ θʌndɝ. hi kəd nɑt hɪɹ ɪt kɹæʃɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ weɪvz, nɑɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə lændlɑkt kɛɹhin.

Tnere was no lightning - he did not see it light his eyelids. There was no thunder. He could not hear it crashing. There were no waves, not in the middle of landlocked Cairhien.

pɛɹɪn snæpt ɪz aɪz oʊpən, ən ði ɪntaɪɝ naɪtmɛɹ bɹoʊk əpɑɹt, vænɪʃɪŋ laɪk ə fɪlm ə fɹɔst ɪkspoʊz tə ðə spɹɪŋ sʌnlaɪt. ðə bɪldɪŋz ɹiəpɪɹd, ðə stʃɹit ɹɪtɝnd, ðə weɪvz ɹitʃɹiɾəd. ðə skaɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə bɔɪlɪŋ blæk tɛmpəst. laɪtnɪŋ ðət wɑz bɹaɪɾ ən waɪt flæʃt ɪn ɪts dɛpθs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ θʌndɝ.

Perrin snapped his eyes open, and the entire nightmare broke apart, vanishing like a film of frost exposed to the spring sunlight. The buildings reappeared, the street returned, the waves retreated. The sky returned to the boiling black tempest. Lightning that was bright and white flashed in its depths, but there was no thunder.

hɑpɝ sæɾ ɑn ðə stʃɹiɾ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. pɛɹɪn wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ðə wʊlf. hi cʊɾə dʒʌmp ðəɹ ɪmiɾiətli, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ i dɪdn laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv duɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ izəli. ðət wəd baɪɾ əɾ ɪm wən i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ɹil wɝld.

Hopper sat on the street a short distance away. Perrin walked over to the wolf. He could have jumped there immediately, of course, but he didn't like the idea of doing everything easily. That would bite at him when he returned to the real world.

jə ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋ, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛn əpɹuvɪŋli.

You grow strong, Young Bull, Hopper sent approvingly.

"aɪ stɪl teɪk tu lɔŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ ɛntɝ, ɪt teɪks mi ə fju mɪnəts tə ɹɪɡeɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. aɪ nid tə bi fæstɝ. ɪn ə bæɾəl wɪð sleɪɝ, ə fju mɪnəts maɪɾ əz wɛl bi ən ɪtɝnəɾi."

"I still take too long," Perrin said, glancing over his shoulder. "Every time I enter, it takes me a few minutes to regain control. I need to be faster. In a battle with Slayer, a few minutes might as well be an eternity."

hɪl nɑt bi soʊ stʃɹɔŋ əz ðiz.

He will not be so strong as these.

"hil stɪl bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "hiz hæd jɪɹz tə lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. aɪ oʊnli dʒʌst stɑɹɾəd."

"He'll still be strong enough," Perrin said. "He's had years to learn to control the wolf dream. I only just started."

hɑpɝ læft. jʌŋ bʊl, jə stɑɹɾəd ðə fɝs taɪm jə keɪm hɪɹ.

Hopper laughed. Young Bull, you started the first time you came here.

"jɛs, bʌɾ aɪ dʒʌst stɑɹɾəd tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ə fju wiks bæk."

"Yes, but I just started training a few weeks back."

hɑpɝ kəntɪnjud læfɪŋ. hi wɑz ɹaɪt, ɪn ə weɪ. pɛɹɪn hæd spɛn tu jɪɹz pɹipɛɹɪŋ, vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ət naɪt. bʌɾ i stɪl niɾəd tə lɝn əz mʌtʃ əz i kʊd. ɪn ə weɪ, hi wɑz ɡlæd fəɹ ðə dɪleɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹaɪəl.

Hopper continued laughing. He was right, in a way. Perrin had spent two years preparing, visiting the wolf dream at night. But he still needed to learn as much as he could. In a way, he was glad for the delay before the trial.

bʌɾ i kəd nɑt dɪleɪ tu lɔŋ. ðə læs hʌnt wɑz əpɑn ðɛm. mɛni ʌv ðə wʊlvz wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ðə nɔɹθ; pɛɹɪn kəd fil əm pæsɪŋ. ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə blaɪt, fəɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðeɪ wɝ muvɪŋ boʊθ ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld ən ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, bʌt ðoʊz hɪɹ dɪd nɑt ʃɪf ðəɹ dɝɛkli. ðeɪ ɹæn, əz pæks.

But he could not delay too long. The Last Hunt was upon them. Many of the wolves were running to the north; Perrin could feel them passing. Running for the Blight, for the Borderlands. They were moving both in the real world and in the wolf dream, but those here did not shift there directly. They ran, as packs.

hi kəd tɛl ðət hɑpɝ lɔŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm. haʊɛvɝ, hi ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd, əz dɪd səm ʌðɝz.

He could tell that Hopper longed to join them. However, he remained behind, as did some others.

"kʌm ɑn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "lɛts faɪn ənʌðɝ naɪtmɛɹ."

"Come on," Perrin said. "Let's find another nightmare."

ðə ɹoʊz mɑɹtʃ wɑz ɪn blum.

The Rose March was in bloom.

ðət wɑz ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl. fju ʌðɝ plæns hæd blumd ɪn ðɪs tɛɹəbəl sʌmɝ, ən ðoʊz ðət dɪd hæd wɪltɪd. bʌt ðə ɹoʊz mɑɹtʃ wɑz blumɪŋ, ən fɪɹsli, hʌnʒɹədz ə ɹɛɾ ɪksploʊʒənz twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɡɑɹɾən fɹeɪmwɝk. vɔɹeɪʃəs ɪnsɛks bʌz fɹəm flaʊɝ tə flaʊɝ, əz ɪf ɛvɹi bi ɪn ðə sɪɾi hæd kʌm hɪɹ tə fid.

That was incredible. Few other plants had bloomed in this terrible summer, and those that did had wilted. But the Rose March was blooming, and fiercely, hundreds of red explosions twisting around the garden framework. Voracious insects buzzed from flower to flower, as if every bee in the city had come here to feed.

ɡɔɪn kɛpt ɪz dɪstəns fɹəm ði ɪnsɛks, bʌt ðə sɛn ə ɹoʊzɪz wɑz soʊ pɝveɪsɪv ðəɾ i fɛl beɪðd ɪn ɪt. wʌns i fɪnɪʃt ɪz wɔk, hɪz kloʊðɪŋ wəd pɹɑbli smɛl ə ðə pɝfjum fəɹ aʊɝz.

Gawyn kept his distance from the insects, but the scent of roses was so pervasive that he felt bathed in it. Once he finished his walk, his clothing would probably smell of the perfume for hours.

ɪleɪn wɑz spikɪŋ wɪð sɛvɹəl ædvaɪzɝz nɪɹ wʌn ə ðə bɛntʃɪz bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl, lɪli-kʌvɝd pɑnd. ʃi wɑz ʃoʊɪŋ əɹ pɹɛɡnənsi, ən simd ɹɑɾi- ænt. hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɹəflɛktəd ðə sʌnlaɪt laɪk ðə sɝfəs ʌv ə mɪɹɝ; ətɑp ðət hɛɹ, ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ lʊkt ɔlmoʊs pleɪn baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən.

Elayne was speaking with several advisors near one of the benches beside a small, lily-covered pond. She was showing her pregnancy, and seemed radi- ant. Her golden hair reflected the sunlight like the surface of a mirror; atop that hair, the Rose Crown of Andor looked almost plain by comparison.

ʃi ɔfən hæd mʌtʃ tə də ðiz deɪz. hid hɝd hʌʃt ɹɪpɔɹts ə ðə wɛpənz ʃi wɑz bɪldɪŋ, ðə wʌnz ʃi θɔt maɪt bi əz paʊɝfəl əz kæptɪv deɪmeɪn. ðə bɛlfndɝz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ fəɹ stʃɹeɪt θɹu ðə naɪts, fɹəm wʌt hid hɝd. keɪɛmlɪn wɑz pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ wɔɹ, ðə sɪɾi əbʌz wɪð æktɪvəɾi. ʃi dɪdn ɔfən əv taɪm fəɹ hɪm, ðoʊ hi wɑz ɡlæd fəɹ wʌt ʃi kəd spɛɹ.

She often had much to do these days. He'd heard hushed reports of the weapons she was building, the ones she thought might be as powerful as captive damane. The bellfounders in Caemlyn had been working for straight through the nights, from what he'd heard. Caemlyn was preparing for war, the city abuzz with activity. She didn't often have time for him, though he was glad for what she could spare.

ʃi smaɪld əɾ ɪm əz i əpɹoʊtʃt, ðən weɪvd ɔf əɹ ətɛndəns fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ʃi wɔk tə hɪm ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə fɑn kɪs ɑn ðə tʃik. "ju lʊk θɔtfəl."

She smiled at him as he approached, then waved off her attendants for the moment. She walked to him and gave him a fond kiss on the cheek. "You look thoughtful."

"ə kɑmən mæləɾi ʌv maɪn leɪtli," hi sɛd. "ju lʊk dɪstʃɹæktəd."

"A common malady of mine lately," he said. "You look distracted."

"ə kɑmən mæləɾi ʌv maɪn leɪtli," ʃi sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz tu mʌtʃ tə də ən nɛvɝ ɪnʌf ə mi tə də ɪt.

"A common malady of mine lately," she said. "There is always too much to do and never enough of me to do it.

"ɪf jə nid tə - "

"If you need to - "

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm. "aɪ nid tə spik tə ju. ən aɪv bɪn toʊl ðəɾ ə wɔk ɝaʊn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz wʌns ə deɪ wɪl bi ɡʊd fəɹ maɪ kɑnstətuʃən."

"No," she said, taking his arm. "I need to speak to you. And I've been told that a walk around the gardens once a day will be good for my constitution."

ɡɔɪn smaɪld, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ðə sɛns ə ɹoʊzɪz ən mʌɾ ɝaʊn ðə pɑnd. ðə sɛns ə laɪf. hi ɡlænst ʌp ət ðə skaɪ əz ðeɪ wɔkt. "aɪ kæn bɪliv haʊ mʌtʃ sʌnlaɪt wiv bɪn siɪŋ hɪɹ. aɪd nɪɹli kənvɪns maɪsɛlf ðət ðə pɝpɛtʃuəl ɡlum wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ənnætʃɹəl."

Gawyn smiled, breathing in the scents of roses and mud around the pond. The scents of life. He glanced up at the sky as they walked. "I can't believe how much sunlight we've been seeing here. I'd nearly convinced myself that the perpetual gloom was something unnatural."

"oʊ, ɪt pɹɑbli ɪz," ʃi sɛd nɑnʃəlɑnli. "ə wik bæk ðə klaʊd kʌvɝ ɪn ændɝ bɹoʊk ɝaʊn keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt noʊwɛɹ ɛls."

"Oh, it probably is," she said nonchalantly. "A week back the cloud cover in Andor broke around Caemlyn, but nowhere else."

"bʌt. . . haʊ?"

"But. . . how?"

ʃi smaɪld. "ɹænd. sʌmθɪŋ i dɪd. hi wɑz ətɑp dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, aɪ θɪŋk. ən ðən . . ."

She smiled. "Rand. Something he did. He was atop Dragonmount, I think. And then . . ."

sʌɾənli, ðə deɪ sim dɑɹkɝ. "ælθɹ əɡɛn," ɡɔɪn spæt. "hi fɑloʊz mi ivən hɪɹ."

Suddenly, the day seemed darker. "Al'Thor again," Gawyn spat. "He follows me even here."

"ivən hɪɹ?" ʃi sɛd wɪð əmjuzmənt. "aɪ bɪliv ðiz ɡɑɹɾənz ɑɹ wɛɹ wi fɝs mɛt hɪm."

"Even here?" she said with amusement. "I believe these gardens are where we first met him."

ɡɔɪn dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ tə ðæt. hi ɡlæns nɔɹθwɝd, tʃɛkɪŋ ðə skaɪ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən. ɑmənəs dɑɹk klaʊdz hʌŋ aʊt ðɛɹ. "hiz ðə fɑðɝ, ɪzən hi?"

Gawyn didn't reply to that. He glanced northward, checking the sky in that direction. Ominous dark clouds hung out there. "He's the father, isn't he?"

"ɪf i wɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪθaʊt mɪsɪŋ ə bit, "ðɛn ɪt wəd bi pɹuɾənt tə haɪd ðət fækt, wʊdn ɪt? ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl bi tɑɹɡəts."

"If he were," Elayne said without missing a beat, "then it would be prudent to hide that fact, wouldn't it? The children of the Dragon Reborn will be targets."

ɡɔɪn fɛl sɪk. hid səspɛktəɾ ɪt ðə moʊmən hid dɪskʌvɝd ðə pɹɛɡnənsi. "bɝn mi," hi sɛd.

Gawyn felt sick. He'd suspected it the moment he'd discovered the pregnancy. "Burn me," he said.

"ɪleɪn, haʊ kəd ju? æftɝ wʌɾ i dɪd tə əɹ mʌðɝ!"

"Elayne, how could you? After what he did to our mother!"

"hi dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə hɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ kən pɹədus wɪtnəs æftɝ wɪt-nɛs ðət wɪl kənfɝm ɪt, ɡɔɪn. mʌðɝ vænɪʃt bɪfɔɹ ɹænd lɪbɝeɪɾɪd keɪɛmlɪn." ðəɹ wɑz ə fɑn lʊk ɪn əɹ aɪz əz ʃi spoʊk ə hɪm. "sʌmθɪŋ ɪz hæpənɪŋ tə hɪm. aɪ kən fil ɪt, fil ɪm tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. klɛnzɪŋ. hi dʒɹaɪvz bæk ðə klaʊdz ən meɪks ðə ɹoʊzɪz blum."

"He did nothing to her," Elayne said. "I can produce witness after wit-ness that will confirm it, Gawyn. Mother vanished before Rand liberated Caemlyn." There was a fond look in her eyes as she spoke of him. "Something is happening to him. I can feel it, feel him changing. Cleansing. He drives back the clouds and makes the roses bloom."

ɡɔɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ʃi θɔt ðə ɹoʊzɪz blum kəz ʌv eɪslæʃθɔɹ? wɛl, lʌv kəd meɪk ə pɝsən θɪŋk stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz, ən wən ðə mæn ʃi spoʊk ʌv wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, pɝhæps səm ɪɹæʃənæləɾi wɑz tə bi ɪkspɛktəd.

Gawyn raised an eyebrow. She thought the roses bloomed because of a/'Thor? Well, love could make a person think strange things, and when the man she spoke of was the Dragon Reborn, perhaps some irrationality was to be expected.

ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə pɑnz smɔl dɑk. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ swɪmɪŋ ðəɹ əz ə tʃaɪld, ðən ɡɛɾɪŋ ən ɪɹfəl fəɹ ɪt. nɑt fɹəm ɪz mʌðɝ, fɹəm ɡɑləd, ðoʊ ɡɔɪnz mʌðɝ hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə stɝn, dɪsəpɔɪntɪd lʊk. hid nɛvɝ toʊld ɛniwʌn ðət hid bɪn swɪmɪŋ oʊnli kəz ɪleɪn hæd pʊʃt ɪm ɪn.

They approached the pond's small dock. He could remember swimming there as a child, then getting an earful for it. Not from his mother, from Galad, though Gawyn's mother had given him a stern, disappointed look. He'd never told anyone that he'd been swimming only because Elayne had pushed him in.

"jɔɹ nɛvɝ gɑnə fɝɡɛt ðæt, ɑɹ ju?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"You're never going to forget that, are you?" Elayne asked.

"wʌt?" hi æskt.

"What?" he asked.

"ju wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə taɪm jə slɪpt ɪndə ðə pɑn dʊɹɪŋ mʌðɝz miɾɪŋ wɪð haʊs fɛɹə."

"You were thinking of the time you slipped into the pond during Mother's meeting with House Farah."

"slɪpt? jə pʊʃt mi!"

"Slipped? You pushed me!"

"aɪ dɪd nʌθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt," ɪleɪn sɛd pɹɪmli. "ju wɝ ʃoʊɪŋ ɔf, bælənsɪŋ ɑn ðə poʊsts."

"I did nothing of the sort," Elayne said primly. "You were showing off, balancing on the posts."

"æn jə ʃʊk ðə dɑk."

"And you shook the dock."

"aɪ stɛpt ɑntu ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "fɔɹsfəli. ɪm ə vɪɡɝəs pɝsən. aɪ hæv ə fɔɹsfəl stʃɹaɪd."

"I stepped onto it," Elayne said. "Forcefully. I'm a vigorous person. I have a forceful stride."

"ə fɔɹsfəl -  ðæts ə daʊnɹaɪt laɪ!"

"A forceful -  That's a downright lie!"

"noʊ, aɪm mɪɹli steɪɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ kɹieɪɾɪvli. aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ naʊ. ɪts ə tælən ʌv aʊɝz. naʊ, ɑɹ jə gɑnə ɹoʊ mi ɑn ðə pɑnd, əɹ nɔɹ?"

"No, I'm merely stating the truth creatively. I'm Aes Sedai now. Its a talent of ours. Now, are you going to row me on the pond, or nor?"

"aɪ . . . ɹoʊ ju? wən dɪd ðət kʌm ʌp?"

"I . . . Row you? When did that come up?"

"dʒʌs naʊ. wɝn jə lɪsnɪŋ?"

"Just now. Weren't you listening?"

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ə bɪmjuz hɛd. "faɪn." bɪhaɪn ðɛm, sɛvɹəl ɡɑɹdz-wɪmən tʊk ʌp poʊsts. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz nɪɹ, ɔfən lɛd baɪ ðə tɔl wʊmən u fænsid hɝsɛlf ən ɪmədʒ ə bɝdʒɪt fɹəm ðə stɔɹiz. ən meɪbi ʃi dɪd lʊk laɪk bɝdʒɪɾ ət ðət - ʃi wɛn baɪ ðə neɪm, ɛniweɪ, ən wɑz sɝvɪŋ əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl.

Gawyn shook a bemused head. "Fine." Behind them, several Guards-women took up posts. They were always near, often led by the tall woman who fancied herself an image of Birgitte from the stories. And maybe she did look like Birgitte at that - she went by the name, anyway, and was serving as Captain-General.

ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ dʒɔɪn baɪ ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɡɹup ʌv ətɛndəns ən mɛs- sɛŋɝz. ðə læs bæɾəl əpɹoʊtʃt, ən ændɝ pɹipɛɹd - ænd, ənfɔɹɾu- nætli, mɛni ʌv ðoʊz pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɪleɪnz dɝɛkt ətɛnʃən.

The Guards were joined by a growing group of attendants and mes- sengers. The Last Battle approached, and Andor prepared - and, unfortu- nately, many of those preparations required Elayne's direct attention.

ðoʊ ɡɔɪn hæd hɝɾ ə kjʊɹiəs stɔɹi ʌv ɪleɪn hævɪŋ bɪn kæɹiɾ ʌp ɑn ðə sɪɾi wɔl ɪn əɹ bɛɾ ə wik əɹ soʊ bæk. soʊ fɑɹ, hi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə pɪn əɹ daʊn ɑn wɛðɝ ðət wɑz tʃɹu əɹ nɑt.

Though Gawyn had heard a curious story of Elayne having been carried up on the city wall in her bed a week or so back. So far, he hadn't been able to pin her down on whether that was true or not.

hi weɪv tə bɝdʒɪt, hu ɡeɪv ɪm ə skaʊl əz i lɛɾ ɪleɪn tə ðə pɑnz smɔl ɹoʊboʊt. "aɪ pɹɑməs nɑt tə dʌmp əɹ ɪn," ɡɔɪn kɔld. ðɛn, ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, "ðoʊ aɪ maɪt ɹoʊ 'fɔɹsfəli' ən ʌpɛn ʌs."

He waved to Birgitte, who gave him a scowl as he led Elayne to the pond's small rowboat. "I promise not to dump her in," Gawyn called. Then, under his breath, "Though I might row 'forcefully' and upend us."

"oʊ, hʌʃ," ɪleɪn sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ daʊn. "pɑndwɔɾɝ wʊdn bi ɡʊd fəɹ ðə beɪbiz."

"Oh, hush," Elayne said, settling down. "Pondwater wouldn't be good for the babies."

"spikɪŋ ʌv wɪtʃ," ɡɔɪn sɛd, pʊʃɪŋ ðə boʊɾ ɔf wɪð ɪz toʊ, ðən stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ɪt. ðə vɛsəl ʃʊk pɹɪkɛɹiəsli əntɪl i sæt daʊn. "ɑɹən jə səpoʊz tə bi wɔkɪŋ fəɹ jəɹ 'kɑnstətuʃən'?"

"Speaking of which," Gawyn said, pushing the boat off with his toe, then stepping into it. The vessel shook precariously until he sat down. "Aren't you supposed to be walking for your 'constitution'?"

"aɪl tɛl mɛlfən aɪ niɾəd tə teɪk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ɹəfɔɹm maɪ mɪskɹiən bɹʌðɝ. jə kən ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð ɔl kaɪnz ə θɪŋz ɪf jəɹ ɡɪvɪŋ sʌmwʌn ə pɹɑpɝ skoʊldɪŋ."

"I'll tell Melfane I needed to take the opportunity to reform my miscreant brother. You can get away with all kinds of things if you're giving someone a proper scolding."

"æn ɪz ðət wʌɾ aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ? ə skoʊldɪŋ?"

"And is that what I'm getting? A scolding?"

"nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz sɑmbɝ. ɡɔɪn ʃɪp ði ɔɹz ən slɪpt əm ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ. ðə pɑnd wɑzn lɑɹdʒ, bɛɹli bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə dʒʌstəfaɪ ə boʊt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə sɝɛnəɾi əbaʊt biɪŋ əpɑn ðə wɔɾɝ, əmɪd ðə pɑnd-ɹʌnɝz ən ðə bʌɾɝflaɪz.

"Not necessarily." Her voice was somber. Gawyn shipped the oars and slipped them into the water. The pond wasn't large, barely big enough to justify a boat, but there was a serenity about being upon the water, amid the pond-runners and the butterflies.

"ɡɔɪn," ɪleɪn sɛd, "waɪ hæv jə kʌm tə keɪɛmlɪn?"

"Gawyn," Elayne said, "why have you come to Caemlyn?"

"ɪts maɪ hoʊm," hi sɛd. "waɪ ʃʊdn aɪ kʌm hɪɹ?"

"It's my home," he said. "Why shouldn't I come here?"

"aɪ wɝiɾ əbaʊt jə dʊɹɪŋ ðə sidʒ. aɪ cʊɾə juz jə ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ. bʌt jə steɪɾ əweɪ."

"I worried about you during the siege. I could have used you in the fighting. But you stayed away."

"aɪ ɪkspleɪn ðæt, ɪleɪn! aɪ wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪld ɪn waɪt taʊɝ pɑlətɪks, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə wɪntɝ snoʊz. ɪt bɝnz mi ðəɾ aɪ kʊdn hɛlp, bʌt ðoʊz wɪmən hæd ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn mi."

"I explained that, Elayne! I was embroiled in White Tower politics, not to mention the winter snows. It burns me that I couldn't help, but those women had their fingers on me."

"aɪm wʌn ʌv 'ðoʊz wɪmən' maɪsɛlf, jə noʊ." ʃi hɛld ʌp əɹ hænd, ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝ.

"I'm one of 'those women' myself, you know." She held up her hand, Great Serpent ring encircling her finger.

"jɔɹ dɪfɹənt," ɡɔɪn sɛd. 'ɛniweɪ, jəɹ ɹaɪt. aɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ʌðɝ əpɑlədʒiz jə ɪkspɛk mi tə meɪk, ðoʊ."

"You're different," Gawyn said. 'Anyway, you're right. I should have been here. I don't know what other apologies you expect me to make, though."

aɪ doʊn ɪkspɛkt ɛni əpɑlədʒiz," ɪleɪn sɛd. "oʊ, ɡɔɪn, aɪ wɑzn tʃæstaɪzɪŋ ju. waɪl aɪ sɝɾənli cʊɾə juz ju, wi mænədʒd. aɪ ɔlsoʊ wɝiɾ əbaʊt jə ɡɛɾɪŋ kɑt bɪtwin dɪfɛndɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ən pɹətɛktɪŋ ɛɡwin. ɪt simz ðət wɝkt aʊɾ əz wɛl. soʊ, aɪ æsk. waɪ hæv jə kʌm hɪɹ naʊ? dʌzn ɛɡwin nid ju?"

I don't expect any apologies," Elayne said. "Oh, Gawyn, I wasn't chastising you. While I certainly could have used you, we managed. I also worried about you getting caught between defending the Tower and protecting Egwene. It seems that worked out as well. So, I ask. Why have you come here now? Doesn't Egwene need you?"

"əpɛɹənli nɑt," ɡɔɪn sɛd, bækɪŋ ðə boʊt. ə mæsɪv dʒɹeɪpɪŋ wɪloʊ ɡɹu fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ə ðə pɑn hɪɹ, hæŋɪŋ daʊn bɹæntʃəz laɪk bɹeɪdz tə dæŋɡəl əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz ɔɹz aʊtsaɪd ðoʊz bɹæntʃəz ən ðə boʊt stɪld.

"wɛl," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ woʊn pɹɪzum tə pɹaɪ ɪndə ðət - ət list, nɑɾ ət ðə moʊmənt. jə ɑɹ ɔlweɪz wɛlkəm hɪɹ, ɡɔɪn. aɪd meɪk jə kæptən.. dʒɛnɝəl ɪf jə æskt, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə wɑn ɪt."

"wʌt meɪks jə seɪ ðæt?"

"What makes you say that?"

"wɛl, juv spɛn ðə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv jəɹ taɪm hɪɹ moʊpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðiz ɡɑɹɾənz."

hi snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli.

He snorted softly.

"ɡɔɪn, jə hævən bɪn spɛndɪŋ taɪm wɪð ɛni ʌv jəɹ fɹɛnz əɹ əkweɪntənsɪz fɹəm ðə pæləs. jə hævən bɪn stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹoʊl ʌv ə pɹɪns əɹ kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl. ɪnstɛd jə mɪɹli . .

"Gawyn, you haven't been spending time with any of your friends or acquaintances from the palace. You haven't been stepping into the role of a prince or Captain-General. Instead you merely . .

. pɑndɝ."

. ponder."

"I think it's been good for me to be here," Gawyn said, taking a deep breath. Some women were walking along the path around the pond, led by a woman with bright red hair that was streaked with white. Dimana was some kind of failed student of the White Tower. Gawyn wasn't quite certain about the nature of the Kin and their relationship with Elayne.

"biɪŋ hɪɹ," hi sɛd, "ɹimaɪndəd mi ʌv maɪ laɪf bɪfɔɹ. ɪts bɪn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli lɪbɝeɪɾɪŋ tə bi fɹi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. fəɹ ə taɪm, aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ aɪ niɾəd tə bi wɪð ɛɡwin. wən aɪ lɛf ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz tə ɹaɪd tə hɝ, ɪt fɛlt laɪk ðə bɛs tʃɔɪs aɪɾ ɛvɝ meɪd. ən jɛt, ʃi simz tə hæv muv bɪɑnd niɾɪŋ mi. ʃiz soʊ kənsɝnd wɪð biɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ, wɪð biɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðət ʃi dʌzn əv ɹum fəɹ ɛniwʌn u woʊn baʊ tə hɝ ɛvɹi wɪm."

"Being here," he said, "reminded me of my life before. It's been particularly liberating to be free of Aes Sedai. For a time, I was sure that I needed to be with Egwene. When I left the Younglings to ride to her, it felt like the best choice I'd ever made. And yet, she seems to have moved beyond needing me. She's so concerned with being strong, with being the Amyrlin, that she doesn't have room for anyone who won't bow to her every whim."

"aɪ daʊt ðəɾ ɪts əz bæɾ əz jə seɪ, ɡɔɪn. ɛɡwin . . . wɛl, ʃiz tə pʊt fɔɹwɝɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ fɹʌnt. kəz ə hɝ juθ, ən ðə weɪ ʃi wɑz ɹeɪz bʌt ʃiz nɑɾ ɛɹəɡənt. noʊ mɔɹ soʊ ðən ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi."

Well, Egwene has armies full of those kinds of people, as do I. What is truly unique is someone who does what I tell them. Better, someone who does what they know I'd tell them, if I had the chance."

"waɪ də aɪ heɪɾ ælθɹ?" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wɛl, ðɛɹz mʌðɝ. bʌɾ ɪts nɑt dʒʌs hɝ. aɪ heɪt wʌt hiz bɪkʌm."

"ɪɡzækli."

"Exactly."

"soʊ ɪts dʒɛləsi," ɪleɪn sɛd sɔfli.

"noʊ. nɑnsɛns. aɪ. . ."

"meɪbi."

hi hæd noʊ ɹɪplaɪ tə ðæt.

"ðɪs," hi sɛd, "kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə wʊmən u pɝsənəli ɹeɪɾɪd ðə blæk ədʒɑ?"

"This," he said, "coming from the woman who personally raided the Black Ajah?"

ɪleɪn blʌʃt. hi kəd tɛl ðət ʃi wɪʃt hid nɛvɝ faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊt ðəɾ ɪvɛnt. "ɪt wɑz niɾəd. ən bɪsaɪdz, aɪ dɪd seɪ 'wi.' jə ən aɪ, wɪv ðɪs tʃɹʌbəl. bɝdʒɪt kips tɛlɪŋ mi aɪ nid tə lɝn tə bi mɔɹ tɛmpɹət. wɛl, jəl nid tə lɝn ðə seɪm θɪŋ, fəɹ ɛɡwinz seɪk. ən ʃi dʌz nid ju, ɡɔɪn. ʃi meɪ nɑt ɹilaɪz ɪt; ʃi meɪ bi kənvɪnst ʃi nidz tə hoʊld ʌp ðə wɝl hɝsɛlf. ʃiz ɹɔŋ."

Birgitte keeps telling me I need to learn to be more temperate. Well, you'll need to learn the same thing, for Egwene's sake. And she does need you, Gawyn. She may not realize it; she may be convinced she needs to hold up the world herself. She's wrong."

ðə boʊt θʌmpt əɡɛns ðə dɑk. ɪleɪn ənʃɪp ði ɔɹz ən hɛld aʊɾ ə hænd. ɡɔɪn klaɪmd aʊt, ðən hɛlpt əɹ ʌp ɑntu ðə dɑk. ʃi ɡɹɪpt ɪz hæn fɑnli. "jul sɔɹɾ ɪɾ aʊt," ʃi sɛd. "aɪm ɹilisɪŋ jə fɹəm ɛni ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi tə bi maɪ kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl. fəɹ naʊ, aɪ woʊn əpɔɪn ənʌðɝ fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd, bʌt jə kən hoʊl ðət taɪɾəl wɪð duɾiz ɪn əbeɪəns. soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ʃoʊ ʌp fəɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl steɪt fʌŋkʃən, jə nidnt wɝi əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðət maɪt bi ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə ju. əl pʌblɪʃ ɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli, saɪɾɪŋ ə nid fəɹ jə tə bi duɪŋ ʌðɝ wɝk ət ði ædvɛn ə ðə læs bæɾəl."

The boat thumped against the dock. Elayne unshipped the oars and held out a hand. Gawyn climbed out, then helped her up onto the dock. She gripped his hand fondly. "You'll sort it out," she said. "I'm releasing you from any responsibility to be my Captain-General. For now, I wont appoint another First Prince of the Sword, but you can hold that title with duties in abeyance. So long as you show up for the occasional state function, you needn't worry about anything else that might be required of you. I will publish it immediately, citing a need for you to be doing other work at the advent of the Last Battle."

"aɪ. . . θæŋk ju," hi sɛd, ðoʊ hi wɑzn sɝɾən i fɛlt ɪt. ɪt saʊndəd tu mʌtʃ laɪk ɛɡwinz ɪnsɪstəns ðəɾ i dɪdnt nid tə ɡɑɹɾ əɹ dɔɹ.

"I. . . Thank you," he said, though he wasn't certain he felt it. It sounded too much like Egwene's insistence that he didn't need to guard her door.

ɪleɪn skwizd ɪz hæn əɡɛn, ðən tɝn ən wɔkt ʌp tə ði æt- tɛndəns. ɡɔɪn wɑtʃt əɹ spik tə ðɛm ɪn ə kɑm toʊn. ʃi sim tə ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ ɹiɡəl baɪ ðə deɪ; ɪt wɑz laɪk wɑtʃɪŋ ə flaʊɝ blɑsəm. hi wɪʃt hid bɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn tə vju ðə pɹɑsɛs fɹəm ðə stɑɹt.

Elayne squeezed his hand again, then turned and walked up to the at- tendants. Gawyn watched her speak to them in a calm tone. She seemed to grow more regal by the day; it was like watching a flower blossom. He wished he'd been in Caemlyn to view the process from the start.

hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf smaɪlɪŋ əz i tɝn tə kəntɪnju hɪz weɪ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊz mɑɹtʃ. hɪz ɹɪɡɹɛts hæd tʃɹʌbəl teɪkɪŋ hoʊl bɪfɔɹ ə hɛlθi doʊs ʌv ɪleɪnz kɛɹəktɝɪstɪk ɑptəmɪzəm. oʊnli ʃi kəd kɔl ə mæn dʒɛləs ən meɪk ɪm fil ɡʊɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt.

He found himself smiling as he turned to continue his way along the Rose March. His regrets had trouble taking hold before a healthy dose of Elayne's characteristic optimism. Only she could call a man jealous and make him feel good about it.

hi pæs θɹu weɪvz ə pɝfjum, filɪŋ ðə sʌn ɑn ɪz nɛk. hi wɔkt wɛɹ i ən ɡɑləd hæd pleɪɾ əz tʃɪlʒɹən, ən i θɔɾ ə hɪz mʌðɝ wɔkɪŋ ðiz ɡɑɹɾənz wɪð bɹaɪn. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ kɛɹfəl ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən wən i mɪsstɛpt, ðən əɹ smaɪlz wən i æktəɾ əz ə pɹɪns ʃʊd. ðoʊz smaɪlz hæd sim laɪk ðə sʌn ɹaɪzɪŋ.

He passed through waves of perfume, feeling the sun on his neck. He walked where he and Galad had played as children, and he thought of his mother walking these gardens with Bryne. He remembered her careful instruction when he misstepped, then her smiles when he acted as a prince should. Those smiles had seemed like the sun rising.

ðɪs pleɪs wɑz hɝ. ʃi lɪvd ɑn, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɪn ɪleɪn - hu lʊk mɔɹ ən mɔɹ laɪk əɹ baɪ ði aʊɝ - ɪn ðə seɪfti ən stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv ændɝz pipəl. hi stɑp bɪsaɪd ðə pɑnd, ðə vɛɹi spɑt wɛɹ ɡɑləd hæd seɪvd ɪm fɹəm dʒɹaʊnɪŋ əz ə tʃaɪld.

This place was her. She lived on, in Caemlyn, in Elayne - who looked more and more like her by the hour - in the safety and strength of Andor's people. He stopped beside the pond, the very spot where Galad had saved him from drowning as a child.

pɝhæps ɪleɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. pɝhæps ælθɹ hædn hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð mɔɹɡeɪsəz dɛθ. ɪf i hæd, ɡɔɪn wəd nɛvɝ pɹuv ɪt. bʌt ðət dɪdn mæɾɝ. ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi kəndɛm tə daɪ ət ðə læs bæɾəl. soʊ waɪ kip heɪɾɪŋ ðə mæn?

Perhaps Elayne was right. Perhaps al'Thor hadn't had anything to do with Morgase's death. If he had, Gawyn would never prove it. But that didn't matter. Rand al'Thor was already condemned to die at the Last Battle. So why keep hating the man?

"ʃi ɪz ɹaɪt," ɡɔɪn wɪspɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə hɔkfliz dæns oʊvɝ ðə sɝfəs ə ðə wɔɾɝ.

"She is right," Gawyn whispered, watching the hawkflies dance over the surface of the water.

"wɝ dʌn, ælθɹ. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, aɪ kɛɹ nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ju."

"We're done, al'Thor. From now on, I care nothing for you."

ɪt fɛlt laɪk ən ɪnɔɹməs weɪt lɪftɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ɡɔɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ, ɹɪlækst saɪ. oʊnli naʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd ɹilist ɪm dɪɾ i ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ ɡɪl hid fɛlt oʊvɝ ɪz æbsəns fɹəm ændɝ. ðət wɑz ɡɔn naʊ, tu.

It felt like an enormous weight lifting from his shoulders. Gawyn let out a long, relaxed sigh. Only now that Elayne had released him did he realize how much guilt he'd felt over his absence from Andor. That was gone now, too.

taɪm tə foʊkəs ɑn ɛɡwin. hi ɹitʃt ɪndə hɪz pɑkət, slɪpɪŋ aʊt ði əsæsənz naɪf, ən hɛld ɪɾ ʌp ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðoʊz ɹɛd stoʊnz. hi dɪɾ əv ə duɾi tə pɹətɛkt ɛɡwin. səpoʊzɪŋ ʃi ɹeɪld əɡɛns hɪm, heɪɾəd hɪm, ən ɛɡzaɪl hɪm; wʊdn ɪt bi wɝθ ðə pʌnɪʃməns ɪf i mænədʒ tə pɹəzɝv əɹ laɪf?

Time to focus on Egwene. He reached into his pocket, slipping out the assassin's knife, and held it up in the sunlight, inspecting those red stones. He did have a duty to protect Egwene. Supposing she railed against him, hated him, and exiled him; wouldn't it be worth the punishments if he managed to preserve her life?

baɪ maɪ mʌðɝz ɡɹeɪv," ə vɔɪs sɛd ʃɑɹpli fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðæt?"

By my mother's grave," a voice said sharply from behind. "Where did you get that?"

ɡɔɪn spʌn. ðə wɪmən hid noʊɾəst ɝliɝ wɝ stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪm ɑn ðə pæθ. dmænə lɛd ðɛm, hɝ hɛɹ stʃɹikt wɪð waɪt, hɝ feɪs ɹɪŋkəld ɝaʊn ði aɪz. wɑznt wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ səpoʊz tə stɑp ðoʊz saɪnz ʌv eɪdʒɪŋ?

Gawyn spun. The women he'd noticed earlier were standing behind him on the path. Dimana led them, her hair streaked with white, her face wrinkled around the eyes. Wasn't working with the Power supposed to stop those signs of aging?

ðəɹ wɝ tu pipəl wɪð hɝ. wʌn wɑz ə plʌmp jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð blæk hɛɹ, ði ʌðɝ ə staʊt wʊmən ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz. ðə sɛkənd wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd spoʊkən; ʃi hæd waɪd, ɪnəsənt-lʊkɪŋ aɪz. ən ʃi sim hɔɹəfaɪd.

There were two people with her. One was a plump young woman with black hair, the other a stout woman in her middle years. The second was the one who had spoken; she had wide, innocent-looking eyes. And she seemed horrified.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðæt, mɑɹɪl?" dmænə æskt.

"What is that, Marille?" Dimana asked.

"aɪ hæv sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ," dmænə kɝɛktəd. "ju ɑɹ ə pɝsən ən nɑɾ ə θɪŋ."

Gawyn raised an eyebrow. What was wrong with this person?

"You're Seanchan?" Gawyn said. Of course. I should have noticed the accent.

mɑɹɪl nɑɾəd vɪɡɝəsli. ə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn. ɡɔɪn fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ðɪs wʊmən hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪn tə kɪl wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ðə θɝd wʊmən ɹɪmeɪn saɪlənt, wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð kjʊɹiəs aɪz. ʃi dɪdn lʊk nɪɹli əz səbsɝviənt.

Marille nodded vigorously. A former damane. Gawyn felt a chill. This woman had been trained to kill with the Power. The third woman remained silent, watching with curious eyes. She didn't look nearly as subservient.

"wi ʃəd bi muvɪŋ ɑn," dmænə sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪzənt ɡʊd fəɹ əɹ tə si θɪŋz ðət ɹimaɪn əɹ ə sintʃæn. kʌm, mɑɹɪl. ðəɾ ɪz mɪɹli ə toʊkən lɔɹd tʃɹəkənd wʌn ɪn bæɾəl, aɪ səspɛkt."

"We should be moving on," Dimana said. "It isn't good for her to see things that remind her of Seanchan. Come, Marille. That is merely a token Lord Trakand won in battle, I suspect."

"No, wait," Gawyn said, holding up a hand. "You recognize this blade?"

mɑɹɪl lʊk tə dmænə, əz ɪf ɹɪkwɛstɪŋ pɝmɪʃən tə ænsɝ. ðə kɪnswʊmən nɑɾəd sʌfɝɪŋli.

Marille looked to Dimana, as if requesting permission to answer. The Kinswoman nodded sufferingly.

"It is a Bloodknife, my Lord," Marille said. "You did not win it in battle, because men do not defeat Bloodknives. They are unstoppable. They only fall when their own blood turns against them."

ɡɔɪn fɹaʊnd. wʌt nɑnsɛns wɑz ðɪs? "soʊ ðɪs ɪz ə sintʃæn wɛpən?"

Gawyn frowned. What nonsense was this? "So this is a Seanchan weapon?"

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," mɑɹɪl sɛd. "kæɹid baɪ ðə blʌdnaɪvz."

"Yes, my Lord," Marille said. "Carried by the Bloodknives."

"It is, but that is also who carries them. Shrouded in the night, sent by the Empress's will - may she live forever - to strike down her foes and die in her name and glory." Marille lowered her eyes farther. "Marille speaks too much. She is sorry."

"aɪ æm sɑɹi," dmænə sɛd, ə hɪn ʌv ɛksæspɝeɪʃən ɪn əɹ toʊn.

"I am sorry," Dimana said, a hint of exasperation in her tone.

"So these . . . Bloodknives," Gawyn said. "They're Seanchan assassins? He felt a deep chill.

kəd ðeɪv lɛf bɪhaɪn suəsaɪd tʃɹups tə kɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ? jɛs. ɪt meɪd sɛns. ðə mɝɾɝɝ wɑznt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

Could they have left behind suicide troops to kill Aes Sedai? Yes. It made sense. The murderer wasn't one of the Forsaken.

mɑɹɪl ʃɹæŋk daʊn fɑɹðɝ əɾ itʃ kwɛstʃən, ən bɪɡæn tə wɪmpɝ.

Gawyn pulled back. The Seanchan treated their damane worse than animals. Marille wouldn't have been told anything specific of what these Bloodknives could do. "Where did you get these damane?" Gawyn asked. "Were any Seanchan soldiers captured? I need to speak with one; an officer, preferably."

"Dimana," the other woman said. She didn't have a Seanchan accent. "What of the sul'dam?

kziə wɑz ə ðə loʊ blʌd."

Kaisea was of the low Blood."

dmænə fɹaʊnd. "kziə ɪz . . . ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl."
