"Please," Gawyn said. "This could save lives."

"vɛɹi wɛl," dmænə sɛd. "weɪt hɪɹ. əl ɹɪtɝn wɪð hɝ." ʃi tʊk əɹ tu tʃɑɹdʒəz təwɔɹd ðə pæləs, livɪŋ ɡɔɪn tə weɪɾ æŋkʃəsli. ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, dmænə ɹɪtɝnd, fɑloʊd baɪ ə tɔl wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ə peɪl ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs wɪθaʊt bɛlt əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. hɝ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ wɑz woʊvən ɪndə ə bɹeɪd, ən ʃi sim dɪtɝmən tə ɹɪmeɪn pɹɪsaɪsli wʌn stɛp bɪhaɪn dmænə - ən ækʃən ðət bɑðɝd ðə kɪnswʊmən, hu sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ðə wʊmən.

"Very well," Dimana said. "Wait here. I will return with her." She took her two charges toward the palace, leaving Gawyn to wait anxiously. A few minutes later, Dimana returned, followed by a tall woman wearing a pale gray dress without belt or embroidery. Her long black hair was woven into a braid, and she seemed determined to remain precisely one step behind Dimana - an action that bothered the Kinswoman, who seemed to be trying to keep an eye on the woman.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ɡɔɪn, ən ðə sʌldəm - ɪnkɹɛɾəbli - ɡɑt daʊn ɑn əɹ niz ən pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hɛd tʌtʃɪŋ ðə dɝt. ðəɹ wɑz ə smuð ɛləɡəns tə ðə boʊɪŋ; fəɹ səm ɹizən, ɪt meɪd ɡɔɪn fil əz ɪf i wɝ biɪŋ mɑkt.

They reached Gawyn, and the sul'dam - incredibly - got down on her knees and prostrated herself on the ground, head touching the dirt. There was a smooth elegance to the bowing; for some reason, it made Gawyn feel as if he were being mocked.

lɔɹd tʃɹəkənd," dmænə sɛd, "ðɪs ɪz kziə. ɔɹəɡən, ət list, ðæts wʌt ʃi ɪnsɪsts ðət wi kɔl əɹ naʊ."

Lord Trakand," Dimana said, "this is Kaisea. Or, at least, that's what she insists that we call her now."

kziə ɪz ə ɡʊd sɝvənt," ðə wʊmən sɛɾ ivənli.

Kaisea is a good servant," the woman said evenly.

"stæn ʌp," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?"

"Stand up," Gawyn said. "What are you doing?"

"kziə hæz bɪn toʊl jə ɑɹ ðə kwinz bɹʌðɝ; jə ɑɹ ə ðə blʌɾ ə ðɪs ɹɛlm, ən aɪm ə loʊli deɪmeɪn"

"Kaisea has been told you are the Queen's brother; you are of the Blood of this realm, and I am a lowly damane"

"deɪmeɪn? jəɹ ə sʌldəm."

"Damane? You're a sul'dam."

"noʊ lɔŋɡɝ," ðə wʊmən sɛd. "aɪ mʌs bi kɑlɝd, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. wɪl jə si ɪt dʌn? kziə ɪz deɪnʒɝəs."

"No longer," the woman said. "I must be collared, great Lord. Will you see it done? Kaisea is dangerous."

dmænə nɑɾəd tə ðə saɪd, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ðeɪ ʃəd spik pɹaɪvətli. ɡɔɪn wɪθdʒɹu wɪð əɹ fɑɹðɝ daʊn ðə ɹoʊz mɑɹtʃ, livɪŋ kziə pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Dimana nodded to the side, indicating they should speak privately. Gawyn withdrew with her farther down the Rose March, leaving Kaisea prostrate on the ground.

"ʃiz ə sʌldəm?" ɡɔɪn æskt. "ɔɹ ɪz ʃi ə deɪmeɪn?"

"She's a sul'dam?" Gawyn asked. "Or is she a damane?"

"ɔl sʌldəm kən bi tʃɹeɪn tə tʃænəl," dmænə ɪkspleɪnd. "ɪleɪn θɪŋks ðət fækt wɪl ʌndɝmaɪn ðɛɹ ɪntaɪɝ kʌltʃɝ wʌns ɹɪvild, soʊ ʃiz hæɾ əs foʊkəs ɑn titʃɪŋ ðə sʌldəm tə æksɛs ðɛɹ paʊɝz. mɛni ɹəfjuz tə ədmɪt ðət ðeɪ kən si ðə wivz, bʌɾ ə fju hæv bɪn ɑnəst wɪð ʌs.

"All sul'dam can be trained to channel," Dimana explained. "Elayne thinks that fact will undermine their entire culture once revealed, so she's had us focus on teaching the sul'dam to access their powers. Many refuse to admit that they can see the weaves, but a few have been honest with us.

tə ə wʊmən, ðeɪv ɪnsɪstəd ðət ðeɪ ʃəd bi meɪd deɪmeɪn"

To a woman, they've insisted that they should be made damane"

ʃi nɑɾəd bæk təwɔɹd kziə. "ðɪs wʌn ɪz moʊs tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ. wi θɪŋk ʃiz ɪntɛnʃənəli wɝkɪŋ tə lɝn ðə wivz soʊ ðət ʃi kən kɹieɪɾ ən 'æksəɾənt,' ən juz əɹ oʊn ɹizənɪŋ əɡɛnst ʌs  - ɪf ʃi dʌz sʌmθɪŋ vaɪələnt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ʃi kən kleɪm ðət wi wɝ ɹɔŋ tə liv əɹ fɹi."

She nodded back toward Kaisea. "This one is most troubling. We think she's intentionally working to learn the weaves so that she can create an 'accident,' and use our own reasoning against us  - if she does something violent with the One Power, she can claim that we were wrong to leave her free."

ə wʊmən u kəd bi tʃɹeɪn tə kɪl wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, hu wɑz nɑt baʊn baɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz, ən u hæɾ ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən tə pɹuv ðət ʃi wɑz deɪnʒɝəs? ɡɔɪn ʃɪvɝd.

A woman who could be trained to kill with the One Power, who was not bound by the Three Oaths, and who had a determination to prove that she was dangerous? Gawyn shivered.

"wi kip səm fɔkɹuɾ ɪn əɹ moʊs deɪz," dmænə sɛd. "aɪ doʊn tɛl jə ðɪs tə wɝi ju, bʌt tə wɔɹn jə ðət wʌt ʃi sɛz ən dʌz meɪ nɑt bi ɹɪlaɪəbəl."

"We keep some forkroot in her most days," Dimana said. "I don't tell you this to worry you, but to warn you that what she says and does may not be reliable."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd. "θæŋk ju."

Gawyn nodded. "Thank you."

dmænə lɛɾ ɪm bæk, ən ðə sʌldəm ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "haʊ meɪ kziə sɝv ju, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd?" hɝ ækʃənz simd ə pɛɹəɾi ʌv mɑɹɪlz səbsɝviəns. wʌt ɡɔɪn hæɾ ɝɪdʒənəli teɪkən fəɹ mɑkɝi wɑzn ðəɾ əɾ ɔl - ɪnstɛd, ɪt wɑz ði ɪmpɝfɪkt ɛfɝts ʌv wʌn u wɑz haɪbɹn tə ɪməteɪt ðə loʊli.

Dimana led him back, and the sul'dam remained on the ground. "How may Kaisea serve you, great Lord?" Her actions seemed a parody of Marille's subservience. What Gawyn had originally taken for mockery wasn't that at all - instead, it was the imperfect efforts of one who was highborn to imitate the lowly.

"hæv jə ɛvɝ sin wʌn ə ðiz bɪfɔɹ?" ɡɔɪn æskt kæʒəwəli, teɪkɪŋ aʊt ðə blʌdnaɪf.

"Have you ever seen one of these before?" Gawyn asked casually, taking out the Bloodknife.

kziə ɡæspt. "wɛɹ dɪd jə faɪn ðæt? hu ɡeɪv ɪt tə ju?" ʃi kɹɪnʒd ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, əz ɪf ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃid stɛpt aʊɾ ə hɝ əsumd ɹoʊl.

Kaisea gasped. "Where did you find that? Who gave it to you?" She cringed almost immediately, as if realizing that she'd stepped out of her assumed role.

"æn əsæsən tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi wɪð ɪt," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wi fɔt, ən i ɡɑɾ əweɪ."

"An assassin tried to kill me with it," Gawyn said. "We fought, and he got away."

"ðæɾ ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd," ðə sintʃæn wʊmən sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs mɔɹ kəntʃɹoʊld.

"That is impossible, great Lord," the Seanchan woman said, her voice more controlled.

"waɪ dʒju seɪ ðæt?"

"Why do you say that?"

"bɪkɔz ɪf jə hæd fɔt wʌn ə ðə blʌdnaɪvz, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, jə wəd bi dɛd. ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə moʊst ɛkspɝt kɪlɝz ɪn ɔl ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ. ðeɪ faɪt ðə moʊst ɹuθləsli, kəz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd."

"Because if you had fought one of the Bloodknives, great Lord, you would be dead. They are the most expert killers in all of the Empire. They fight the most ruthlessly, because they are already dead."

"suəsaɪd tʃɹups." ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd. "du juv ɛni ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt ðɛm?"

"Suicide troops." Gawyn nodded. "Do you have any information about them?"

kziəz feɪs ɡɹu kənflɪktɪd.

Kaisea's face grew conflicted.

"ɪf aɪ si jə liʃt?" ɡɔɪn æskt. "wɪl jə ænsɝ mi ðɛn?"

"If I see you leashed?" Gawyn asked. "Will you answer me then?"

"maɪ lɔɹd!" dmænə sɛd. "ðə kwin wəd nɛvɝ əlaʊ ɪt!"

"My Lord!" Dimana said. "The Queen would never allow it!"

"aɪl æsk hɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ kæn pɹɑməs ðət jəl bi liʃt, kaɪ-si bʌɾ aɪ kən pɹɑməs əl ɪntɝsid wɪð ðə kwin fəɹ ju."

"I'll ask her," Gawyn said. "I can't promise that you'll be leashed, Kai-sea but I can promise I'll intercede with the Queen for you."

"ju ɑɹ paʊɝfəl ən stʃɹɔŋ, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd," kziə sɛd. "ænd waɪz ɪndid. ɪf jəl də ðɪs θɪŋ, kziə wɪl ænsɝ ju."

"You are powerful and strong, great Lord," Kaisea said. "And wise indeed. If you will do this thing, Kaisea will answer you."

dmænə ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɡɔɪn.

Dimana glared at Gawyn.

"spik," ɡɔɪn sɛd tə ðə sʌldəm.

"Speak," Gawyn said to the sul'dam.

"blʌdnaɪvz də nɑt laɪv lɔŋ," kziə sɛd. "wʌns ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɪvən ə duɾi, ðeɪ də nɑt ɹɛs fɹəm ɪt.

"Bloodknives do not live long," Kaisea said. "Once they are given a duty, they do not rest from it.

ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɹæntəɾ əbɪləɾiz fɹəm ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɹɪŋz ðət meɪk əm ɪndə ɡɹeɪt wɔɹiɝz."

They are granted abilities from the Empress, may she live forever, ter'angreal rings that make them into great warriors."

"ðoʊz blɝ ðɛɹ fɔɹmz," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wɛn ðeɪ ɑɹ nɪɹ ʃædoʊ."

"Those blur their forms," Gawyn said. "When they are near shadow."

"jɛs," kziə sɛd, saʊndɪŋ sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i nu ðɪs. "ðeɪ kænɑt bi dɪfiɾəd. bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðɛɹ oʊn blʌd wɪl kɪl ðɛm."

"Yes," Kaisea said, sounding surprised that he knew this. "They cannot be defeated. But eventually, their own blood will kill them."

"ðɛɹ oʊn blʌd?"

"Their own blood?"

"ðeɪ ɑɹ pɔɪzən baɪ ðɛɹ sɝvəs. wʌns ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɪvən ə tʃɑɹdʒ, ðeɪ ɔfən wɪl nɑt læs mɔɹ ðən ə fju wiks. ət moʊst, ðeɪ sɝvaɪv ə mʌnθ."

"They are poisoned by their service. Once they are given a charge, they often will not last more than a few weeks. At most, they survive a month."

ɡɔɪn hɛld ʌp ðə naɪf, dɪstɝbd. "soʊ wi oʊnli nid tə weɪɾ əm aʊt."

Gawyn held up the knife, disturbed. "So we only need to wait them out."

kziə læft. "ðæt wɪl nɑt hæpən. bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ daɪ, ðəl si ðɛɹ duɾi fʊlfɪld."

Kaisea laughed. "That will not happen. Before they die, they will see their duty fulfilled."

"ðɪs wʌn ɪz kɪlɪŋ pipəl sloʊli," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wʌn ɛvɹi fju deɪz. ə hændfʊl soʊ fɑɹ."

"This one is killing people slowly," Gawyn said. "One every few days. A handful so far."

"tɛsts," kziə sɛd. "pɹɑɾɪŋ fəɹ wiknəsəz ən stʃɹɛŋkθs, lɝnɪŋ wɛɹ ðeɪ kən stʃɹaɪk wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin. ɪf oʊnli ə fju ɑɹ dɛd, ðən juv nɑt jɛt sin ðə fʊl paʊɝ ə ðə blʌdnaɪf. ðeɪ də nɑt liv ə 'hændfʊl' ʌv dɛd, bʌt dʌzənz."

"Tests," Kaisea said. "Prodding for weaknesses and strengths, learning where they can strike without being seen. If only a few are dead, then you have not yet seen the full power of the Bloodknife. They do not leave a 'handful' of dead, but dozens."

"ənlɛs aɪ stɑp hɪm," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ ɪz wiknəsəz?"

"Unless I stop him," Gawyn said. "What are his weaknesses?"

kziə læft əɡɛn. "wiknəsəz? ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, dɪɾ aɪ nɑt seɪ ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə faɪnəst wɔɹiɝz ɪn sintʃæn, ɛnhænst ən eɪɾəd baɪ ði ɛmpɹɛsəz feɪvɝ, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ?"

Kaisea laughed again. "Weaknesses? Great Lord, did I not say that they are the finest warriors in Seanchan, enhanced and aided by the Empress's favor, may she live forever?"

faɪn. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðɛn? ɪt hɛlps ði əsæsən wən hiz ɪn ʃædoʊ? haʊ kən aɪ stɑp ɪt fɹəm wɝkɪŋ? pɝhæps laɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə tɔɹtʃɪz?"

Fine. What about the ter'angreal, then? It helps the assassin when he is in shadow? How can I stop it from working? Perhaps light a large number of torches?"

"ju kænɑɾ əv laɪt wɪθaʊt ʃædoʊ, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, ðə wʊmən sɛd. "kɹieɪt mɔɹ laɪt, ən jəl kɹieɪt mɔɹ ʃædoʊz."

"You cannot have light without shadow, great Lord, the woman said. "Create more light, and you will create more shadows."

"ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ."

"There has to be a way."

"kziə ɪz sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz wʌn, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, jəl faɪn ɪt." ðə wʊmənz ɹɪspɑns hæɾ ə smʌɡ ɹoʊn tə ɪt. "ɪf kziə meɪ sədʒɛst, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd? kaʊn jɝsɛlf fɔɹtʃənət tə hæv sɝvaɪv faɪɾɪŋ ə blʌdnaɪf. jə mʌs nɑɾ əv bɪn ɪz əɹ əɹ tʃɹu tɑɹɡət. ɪt wəd bi pɹuɾənt tə haɪd jɝsɛlf əntɪl ə mʌnθ əz pæst. əlaʊ ði ɛmpɹɛs - meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ-__tə əkɑmplɪʃ əɹ wɪl, ən blɛs ði oʊmənz ðət jə wɝ ɡɪvən wɔɹnɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ɪskeɪp ən lɪv."

"Kaisea is certain that if there is one, great Lord, you will find it." The woman's response had a smug rone to it. "If Kaisea may suggest, great Lord? Count yourself fortunate to have survived fighting a Bloodknife. You must not have been his or her true target. It would be prudent to hide yourself until a month has passed. Allow the Empress - may she live forever-__to accomplish her will, and bless the omens that you were given warning enough to escape and live."

"ðæts ɪnʌf ə ðæt," dmænə sɛd. "aɪ tʃɹʌs juv wʌt jə wɪʃ, lɔɹd tʃɹəkənd?"

"That's enough of that," Dimana said. "I trust you have what you wish, Lord Trakand?"

"jɛs, θæŋk ju," ɡɔɪn sɛd, dɪstɝbd. hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst əz kziə ɹoʊz ən ðə kɪnswʊmən lɛɾ əɹ tʃɑɹdʒ əweɪ.

"Yes, thank you," Gawyn said, disturbed. He barely noticed as Kaisea rose and the Kinswoman led her charge away.

kaʊn jɝsɛlf fɔɹtʃənət tə hæv sɝvaɪvd. . . jə mʌs nɑt tʃɹuli hæv bɪn ɪz tɑɹɡət. . .

Count yourself fortunate to have survived. . . you must not truly have been his target. . .

ɡɔɪn tɛstəd ðə θɹoʊɪŋ naɪf ɪn ɪz hænz. ðə tɑɹɡət wɑz ɛɡwin, ɑbviəsli. "waɪ ɛls wəd ðə sintʃæn ɪkspɛn sətʃ ə paʊɝfəl wɛpən? pɝhæps ðeɪ θɔɾ əɹ dɛθ wəd bɹɪŋ daʊn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Gawyn tested the throwing knife in his hands. The target was Egwene, obviously. "Why else would the Seanchan expend such a powerful weapon? Perhaps they thought her death would bring down the White Tower.

ɛɡwin hæd tə bi wɔɹnd. ɪf ɪt meɪɾ əɹ æŋɡɹi ət hɪm, ɪf ɪt flu ɪn ðə feɪs ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑntəd, hi hæd tə bɹɪŋ əɹ ðɪs ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ɪt kəd seɪv əɹ laɪf.

Egwene had to be warned. If it made her angry at him, if it flew in the face of what she wanted, he had to bring her this information. It could save her life.

hi wɑz stɪl stændɪŋ ðəɹ - kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɛɡwin -  wən ə sɝvən ɪn ɹɛɾ ən waɪt faʊn hɪm. ʃi kæɹiɾ ə pleɪt wɪð ə sild ɛnvəloʊp ɑn ɪt. "maɪ lɔɹd ɡɔɪn?"

He was still standing there - considering how to approach Egwene -  when a servant in red and white found him. She carried a plate with a sealed envelope on it. "My Lord Gawyn?"

"wʌts ðɪs?" ɡɔɪn æskt, teɪkɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ ən juzɪŋ ðə blʌd-naɪf tə kʌɾ ɪɾ oʊpən əlɔŋ ðə tɑp.

"What's this?" Gawyn asked, taking the letter and using the Blood-knife to cut it open along the top.

"fɹʌm tɑɹ vəlɑn," ðə sɝvən sɛd, boʊɪŋ. "ɪt keɪm θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ."

"From Tar Valon," the servant said, bowing. "It came through a gateway."

ɡɔɪn ənfoʊldəd ðə θɪk ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ ɪnsaɪd. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz sɪlvi-ɑnəz skɹɪpt.

Gawyn unfolded the thick sheet of paper inside. He recognized Silvi-ana's script.

ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd. ɪt ɹɛd. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz θɝoʊli dɪspliz tə dɪskʌvɝ jəɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. jə wɝ nɛvɝ ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə liv ðə sɪɾi. ʃiz æsk mi tə sɛn ðɪs mɪsɪv, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðət juv bɪn ɡɪvən æmpəl taɪm tə aɪɾəl ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. jəɹ pɹɛzəns ɪz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən jə ɑɹ tə ɹɪtɝn wɪð ɔl heɪst.

Gawyn Trakand. it read. The Amyrlin was thoroughly displeased to discover your departure. You were never instructed to leave the city. She has asked me to send this missive, explaining that you have been given ample time to idle in Caemlyn. Your presence is required in Tar Valon, and you are to return with all haste.

ɡɔɪn ɹɛd ðə lɛɾɝ, ðən ɹɛɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn. ɛɡwin skɹimd əɾ ɪm fəɹ dɪstɝbɪŋ əɹ plænz, ɔl bʌt θɹu hɪm aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ən ʃi wɑz dɪspliz tə dɪskʌvɝ hid lɛf ðə sɪɾi? wʌd ʃi ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə du? hi ɔlmoʊs læft.

Gawyn read the letter, then read it again. Egwene screamed at him for disturbing her plans, all but threw him out of the Tower, and she was displeased to discover he'd left the city? What did she expect him to do? He almost laughed.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ðə sɝvən æskt. "wʊd jə laɪk tə sɛn ə ɹɪplaɪ?" ðəɹ wɑz peɪpɝ ən pɛn ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ. "ðeɪ ɪmplaɪd ðət wʌn wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd.'

"My Lord?" the servant asked. "Would you like to send a reply?" There was paper and pen on the tray. "They implied that one would be expected.'

"sɛn əɹ ðɪs,' ɡɔɪn sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ðə blʌdnaɪf ɑntu ðə tʃɹeɪ. hi fɛl soʊ æŋɡɹi, sʌɾənli, ən ɔl θɔts ə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ flɛɾ ɪz maɪnd. fleɪmɪŋ wʊmən!

"Send her this,' Gawyn said, tossing the Bloodknife onto the tray. He felt so angry, suddenly, and all thoughts of returning fled his mind. Flaming woman!

"æn tɛl hɝ," hi æɾəd æftɝ ə moʊməns θɔt, "ðæt ði əsæsən ɪz sintʃæn, ən kæɹiz ə spɛʃəl tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət meɪks ɪm dɪfəkəl tə si ɪn ʃædoʊz. bɛs tə kip ɛkstʃɹə laɪts bɝnɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ mɝɾɝz wɝ tɛsts ɡeɪdʒ əɹ dɪfɛnsəz. ʃiz ðə tʃɹu tɑɹɡət. ɛmfəsaɪz ðət ði əsæsən ɪz vɛɹi, vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs - bʌt nɑt ðə pɝsən ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz. ɪf ʃi nidz pɹuf, ʃi kən kʌm tɔk tə səm ə ðə sintʃæn hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn."

"And tell her," he added after a moment's thought, "that the assassin is Seanchan, and carries a special ter'angreal that makes him difficult to see in shadows. Best to keep extra lights burning. The other murders were tests gauge our defenses. She is the true target. Emphasize that the assassin is very, very dangerous - but not the person she thought it was. If she needs proof, she can come talk to some of the Seanchan here in Caemlyn."

ðə sɝvən lʊk pɝplɛkst, bʌt wən i sɛd nʌθɪŋ fɝðɝ, ðə wʊmən ɹitʃɹiɾəd.

The servant looked perplexed, but when he said nothing further, the woman retreated.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə kul ɪz ɹeɪdʒ. hi wʊdnt ɡoʊ bæk, nɑt naʊ. nɑt wən ɪt wəd lʊk əz ɪf hid kʌm kɹɔlɪŋ bæk əɾ əɹ kəmænd. ʃi hæɾ əɹ "kɛɹfəl plænz ən tʃɹæps." ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi dɪdnt nid hɪm. ʃi wəɾ əv tə də wɪθaʊɾ ɪm fəɹ ə waɪl, ðɛn.

He tried to cool his rage. He wouldn't go back, not now. Not when it would look as if he'd come crawling back at her command. She had her "careful plans and traps." She had said she didn't need him. She would have to do without him for a while, then.

Judgment

aɪ wɑn ðə skaʊts aʊt wɑtʃɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd fɔɹsfəli. "ivən dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹaɪəl." "ðə meɪɾənz woʊn laɪk ðɪs, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," səlɪn sɛd. "nɑɾ ɪf ɪt meɪks əm mɪs ðə tʃæns tə dæns ðə spɪɹz."

I want the scouts out watching," Perrin said forcefully. "Even during the trial." "The Maidens won't like this, Perrin Aybara," Sulin said. "Not if it makes them miss the chance to dance the spears."

dænɪl fɹaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ kənfjuzd. wɛl, pɛɹɪn wɑz kənfjuzd, tu. kənfjuzd ən ɪnkɹisɪŋli sɝɾən. ɪt simd ə kɑntʃɹədɪkʃən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu.

Dannil frowned, looking confused. Well, Perrin was confused, too. Confused and increasingly certain. It seemed a contradiction, but it was true.

ðə kæmp wɑz bɪzi, hɪz ɑɹmiz ɡæðɝɪŋ tə mit ðə waɪtkloʊks. nɑɾ ɪz ɑɹmi, hɪz ɑɹmiz.

The camp was busy, his armies gathering to meet the Whitecloaks. Not his army, his armies.

ðəɹ wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ dɪvɪʒən əmʌŋ ðɛm. ɑɹ-ɡændə ən ɡælɛn dʒɑsəlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ fəɹ pəzɪʃən, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɹɪzɛntɪŋ ðə nuɝ bænz ə mɝsənɛɹiz, ðə fɔɹmɝ ɹɛfjudʒiz mæʃt bɪtwin əm ɔl. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, ði il, əluf ən duɪŋ əz ðeɪ wɪʃt.

There was so much division among them. Ar-ganda and Gallenne jostling one another for position, the Two Rivers men resenting the newer bands of mercenaries, the former refugees mashed between them all. And, of course, the Aiel, aloof and doing as they wished.

aɪm gɑnə dɪsbæn ðɛm, pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪmsɛlf. wʌt dʌz ɪt ?næɾɝ? ɪt bɑðɝɾ ɪm nʌnðəlɛs.

I'm going to disband them, Perrin told himself. What does it ?natter? It bothered him nonetheless.

It was a disorderly way to run a camp.

ɛniweɪ, pɛɹɪnz pipəl hæd moʊsli ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm ðɪs leɪɾəst bʌbəl ʌv ivəl. nʌn ə ðə wəd pɹɑbli lʊk ət ðɛɹ wɛpənz əɡɛn ðə seɪm weɪ, bʌt ðə wundəd hæd bɪn hild ən ðə tʃænlɝz wɝ ɹɛstəd.

Anyway, Perrin's people had mostly recovered from this latest bubble of evil. None of the would probably look at their weapons again the same way, but the wounded had been Healed and the channelers were rested.

ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd nɑt bɪn plizd ət ðə dɪleɪ, wɪtʃ hæɾ ɪkstɛndəd lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd pɹɑbli ɪkspɛktəd. bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd niɾəd ðə taɪm, fəɹ ə nʌmbɝ ə ɹizənz.

The Whitecloaks had not been pleased at the delay, which had extended longer than they had probably expected. But Perrin had needed the time, for a number of reasons.

"dænɪl," hi sɛd. "maɪ waɪf əz jə mɪkst ʌp ɪn əɹ plɑts tə pɹətɛk mi, aɪ əsum."

"Dannil," he said. "My wife has you mixed up in her plots to protect me, I assume."

dænɪl stɑɹɾəd. "haʊ - "

"aɪl ɡoʊ, ɪf ɪt tɝnz bæd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌt doʊn dʒʌmp tə ɪt tu ɝli. aɪ woʊn əv ðɪs tɝn ɪndə ə blʌdbæθ kəz wʌn ə ðə waɪtkloʊks lɛts aʊɾ ə kɝs ət ðə ɹɔŋ taɪm. weɪt fəɹ maɪ sɪɡnəl.

Understood?"

Perrin needed to be done with this all. Free of it. Now. Because, over these last few days, it had begun to feel natural to him. I'm just a ... He trailed off. Just a what? A blacksmith? Could he say that anymore? What was he?

ʌp əhɛd, nil sæɾ ɑn ə stʌmp nɪɹ ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs fju deɪz, ðə juθfəl æʃəmən soʊlʒɝ ən ɡɔl hæd skaʊɾəd aʊɾ ɪn sɛvɹəl dɝɛkʃənz ət pɛɹɪnz ɔɹɾɝz, tə si ɪf ɡeɪtweɪz wɝkt ɪf wʌn ɡɑt fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ fɹəm kæmp. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, ɪt tɝn aʊt ðeɪ dɪd, ðoʊ wʌn hæd ɡoʊ fəɹ aʊɝz tə ɪskeɪp ði ɪfɛkt.

Up ahead, Neald sat on a stump near the Traveling ground. During the last few days, the youthful Asha'man soldier and Gaul had scouted out in several directions at Perrin's orders, to see if gateways worked if one got far enough away from camp. Sure enough, it turned out they did, though one had go for hours to escape the effect.

niðɝ nil nɔɹ ɡɔl hæd noʊɾəd ɛni sɔɹɾ ə tʃeɪnʒ ʌðɝ ðən ðə wiv fəɹ ɡeɪtweɪz wɝkɪŋ əɡɛn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bæɹiɝ əɹ vɪzəbəl ɪndəkeɪʃən ɑn ðɪs saɪd, bʌɾ ɪf pɛɹɪn ɡɛst ɹaɪt, ði ɛɹiə wɛɹ ɡeɪtweɪz dɪdnt wɝk mætʃt ɪɡzækli ði ɛɹiə kʌvɝd baɪ ðə doʊm ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

Neither Neald nor Gaul had noted any sort of change other than the weave for gateways working again. There was no barrier or visible indication on this side, but if Perrin guessed right, the area where gateways didn't work matched exactly the area covered by the dome in the wolf dream.

ðət wɑz ðə doʊmz pɝpəs, ən ðət wɑz waɪ sleɪɝ ɡɑɹɾəd ɪt. ɪt wɑzn əbaʊt hʌntɪŋ ðə wʊlvz, ðoʊ hi ʃʊɹli dɪd ðət wɪð plɛʒɝ. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz kɑzɪŋ boʊθ ðə doʊm ən ðə pɹɑbləmz wɪð ði æʃəmən.

That was the dome's purpose, and that was why Slayer guarded it. It wasn't about hunting the wolves, though he surely did that with pleasure. Something was causing both the dome and the problems with the Asha'man.

"I think someone's setting a trap for us," Perrin said softly. "Boxing us in. I've sent some others out to look for the thing causing this; it's probably some kind of object of the One Power." He worried that it might be hidden in the wolf dream. Could something there produce an effect in the real world?

"naʊ, jəɹ ʃʊɹ jə kæn kɹieɪt ɡeɪtweɪz əɾ ɔl? nɑɾ ivən tə ʌðɝ pɔɪns nɪɹbaɪ, ɪnsaɪd ði ɪfɛktəɾ ɛɹiə?"

nild ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

ðə ɹulz ɑɹ dɪfɹən ɑn ðɪs saɪd, ðɛn, pɛɹɪn θɔt. ɔɹ, ət list ɪt wɝks dɪfɹənli ɑn tʃɹævlɪŋ ðən ɪt dʌz ɑn ʃɪftɪŋ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. "nild, jə sɛd wɪð ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ɡeɪtweɪz -  juzɪŋ ə sɝkəl - jə kəd muv ði ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi θɹu ɪn ə fju aʊɝz?"

The rules are different on this side, then, Perrin thought. Or, at least it works differently on Traveling than it does on shifting in the wolf dream. "Neald, you said with the larger gateways -  using a circle - you could move the entire army through in a few hours?"

wi kəd mɑɹtʃ ði ɑɹmi aʊt tə ðət pɔɪn bɪɑn ði ɪfɛkt, ðoʊ, ən ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðɛɹ."

We could march the army out to that point beyond the effect, though, and escape from there."

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, pɛɹɪn səspɛktəd ðət wʊdn du. hɑpɝ hæd kɔl ðɪs ə θɪŋ ə ðə dip pæst.

Unfortunately, Perrin suspected that wouldn't do. Hopper had called this a thing of the deep past.

ðət mɛn ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡʊd tʃæns sleɪɝ wɑz wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə fɔɹseɪkən. əɹ i wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən hɪmsɛlf. pɛɹɪn hæd nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd ðæt. iðɝ weɪ, ðə wʌnz plænɪŋ ðɪs tʃɹæp wəd bi wɑtʃɪŋ. ɪf ɪz ɑɹmi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp, ði ɛnəmi wəd spɹɪŋ ɪts tʃɹæp əɹ ðeɪd muv ðə doʊm.

That meant there was a good chance Slayer was working with the Forsaken. Or he was one of the Forsaken himself. Perrin had never considered that. Either way, the ones planning this trap would be watching. If his army tried to escape, the enemy would spring its trap or they'd move the dome.

ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd bɪn fulɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɪð ðoʊz bɑksəz ən hæd pleɪst əm hɪɹ. ən ðəɹ wɑz ɪz pɪktʃɝ, biɪŋ dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd. wɑz ɪɾ ɔl pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs tʃɹæp, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz? deɪnʒɝz. soʊ mɛni deɪnʒɝz hʌntɪŋ hɪm.

The Forsaken had been fooling the Shaido with those boxes and had placed them here. And there was his picture, being distributed. Was it all part of this trap, whatever it was? Dangers. So many dangers hunting him.

wɛl, wʌd jə ɪkspɛkt, hi θɔt. ɪts tɑɹmən ɡdən.

Well, what did you expect, he thought. It's Tarmon Gai'don.

"aɪ wɪʃ ɛlaɪəs wəd ɹɪtɝn," hi sɛd. hid sɛn ðə mæn ɑn ə spɛʃəl skaʊɾɪŋ mɪʃən ə hɪz oʊn.

"I wish Elyas would return," he said. He'd sent the man on a special scouting mission of his own.

"dʒʌs bi ɹɛɾi, nild. dænɪl, ɪɾəd bi bɛst ɪf jud ɡoʊ pæs maɪ kɔʃənz ɑn tə jəɹ mɛn. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛni æksəɾənts."

"Just be ready, Neald. Dannil, it'd be best if you'd go pass my cautions on to your men. I don't want any accidents."

dænɪl ən nild wɛn ðɛɹ sɛpɹət weɪz, ən pɛɹɪn wɔk tə ðə hɔɹs pɪkəts tə faɪn stɛpɝ. ɡɔl, kwaɪəɾ əz ðə wɪnd, fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪd hɪm.

Dannil and Neald went their separate ways, and Perrin walked to the horse pickets to find Stepper. Gaul, quiet as the wind, fell in beside him.

sʌmwʌnz pʊlɪŋ ə snɛɹ taɪt, pɛɹɪn θɔt, sloʊli, ɪntʃ baɪ ɪntʃ, ɝaʊnd ?naɪ lɛɡ. pɹɑbli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə faɪt ðə waɪtkloʊks. æftɝwɝd, hɪz ɑɹmi wəd bi wikən ən wundəd. izi pɪkɪŋz. ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm ə tʃɪl tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪf hid ɡɔn tə bæɾəl wɪð dəmədʒɹɾ ɝliɝ, ðə tʃɹæp maɪɾ əv bɪn spɹʌŋ ɹaɪt ðɛn. ðə tʃɹaɪəl sʌɾənli tʊk ɑn ɪnɔɹməs ɪmpɔɹt.

Someone's pulling a snare tight, Perrin thought, slowly, inch by inch, around ?ny leg. Probably waiting for him to fight the Whitecloaks. Afterward, his army would be weakened and wounded. Easy pickings. It gave him a chill to realize that if he'd gone to battle with Damodred earlier, the trap might have been sprung right then. The trial suddenly took on enormous import.

pɛɹɪn hæd tə faɪn ə weɪ tə fɔɹstɔl ə bæɾəl əntɪl i kəd ɡɛt tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim wʌn mɔɹ taɪm. ɪn ɪt, pɝhæps i kəd faɪn ə weɪ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə doʊm ən fɹi hɪz pipəl.

Perrin had to find a way to forestall a battle until he could get to the wolf dream one more time. In it, perhaps he could find a way to destroy the dome and free his people.

"ju tʃeɪnʒ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɡɔl sɛd.

"You change, Perrin Aybara," Gaul said.

"wʌts ðæt?" pɛɹɪn sɛd, teɪkɪŋ stɛpɝ fɹəm ə ɡɹum.

"What's that?" Perrin said, taking Stepper from a groom.

"ðɪs ɪz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ," ɡɔl ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪɾ ɪz ɡʊd tə si jə stɑp pɹoʊ-tɛstɪŋ əbaʊt biɪŋ tʃif. ɪts bɛɾɝ tə si jə ɛndʒɔɪ kəmænd."

"This is a good thing," Gaul replied. "It is good to see you stop pro-testing about being chief. It is better to see you enjoy command."

"aɪv stɑpt pɹətɛstɪŋ kəz aɪ hæv bɛɾɝ θɪŋz tə du," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn aɪ doʊn ɛndʒɔɪ biɪŋ ɪn kəmænd. aɪ də ɪt kəz aɪ hæv tə."

"I've stopped protesting because I have better things to do," Perrin said. "And I don't enjoy being in command. I do it because I have to."

ɡɔl nɑɾəd, əz ɪf i θɔt pɛɹɪn wɝ əɡɹiɪŋ wɪð hɪm.

Gaul nodded, as if he thought Perrin were agreeing with him.

il. pɛɹɪn swʌŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. "lɛts ɡoʊ ɑn, ðɛn. ðə kɑləm ɪz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə mɑɹtʃ."

Aiel. Perrin swung into the saddle. "Let's go on, then. The column is starting to march."

"ɔf wɪð ju," feɪl sɛd tə ɝɑvin. "ði ɑɹmi ɪz muvɪŋ aʊt."

"Off with you," Faile said to Aravine. "The army is moving out."

ɝɑvin kɝtsiɾ ən muv tə pæs ði ɔɹɾɝz tə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz. feɪl wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt ðɪs deɪ wəd bɹɪŋ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd ðoʊz u steɪd bɪhaɪn tə bɹeɪk kæmp ən bi ɹɛɾi tə mɑɹtʃ, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs.

Aravine curtsied and moved to pass the orders to the refugees. Faile wasn't certain what this day would bring, but she wanted those who stayed behind to break camp and be ready to march, just in case.

əz ɝɑvin lɛft, feɪl noʊɾəst ɑldin ðə bʊkkipɝ dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɝ. hi dɪd sim tə bi vɪzəɾɪŋ ɝɑvin kwaɪɾ ɔfən leɪtli. pɝhæps hid faɪnəli ɡɪvən ʌp ɑn ɹɛlə.

As Aravine left, Faile noticed Aldin the bookkeeper joining her. He did seem to be visiting Aravine quite often lately. Perhaps he'd finally given up on Arrela.

ʃi heɪsən təwɔɹd ðə tɛnt. ɑn əɹ weɪ, ʃi pæs flæn bɑɹstɪɹ, dʒɑn ɡeɪɛlɪn ən mɑɹɛk kɔɹmɝ tʃɛkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ bɑstʃɹɪŋz ən æɹoʊ flɛtʃɪŋz. ɔl θɹi lʊkt ʌp əɾ əɹ ən weɪvd.

She hastened toward the tent. On her way, she passed Flann Barstere, Jon Gaelin and Marek Cormer checking over their bowstrings and arrow fletchings. All three looked up at her and waved.

ðəɹ sim tə bi ə sɛns ə ɹɪlif ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, wɪtʃ wɑz ə ɡʊd saɪn. wʌns, ðiz mɛn hæd lʊkt əʃeɪmd wən ðeɪd sin hɝ, əz ɪf ðeɪ fɛl bæd fəɹ ðə weɪ pɛɹɪn hæd simɪŋli dælid wɪð bɹəleɪn dʊɹɪŋ feɪlz æbsəns.

There seemed to be a sense of relief in their eyes, which was a good sign. Once, these men had looked ashamed when they'd seen her, as if they felt bad for the way Perrin had seemingly dallied with Berelain during Faile's absence.

feɪl spɛndɪŋ taɪm wɪð bɹəleɪn, mɪkst wɪð ðə fɔɹməl dɪnʌnsieɪʃən ə ðə ɹumɝz, wɑz wɝkɪŋ tə kənvɪns ðə kæmp ðət nʌθɪŋ ɪnəpɹoʊpɹiɪt hæd hæpənd. ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, ɪt sim ðət feɪl seɪvɪŋ bɹəleɪnz laɪf dʊɹɪŋ ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl hæd hæd ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɪfɛkt ɪn tʃeɪnʒɪŋ pipəlz maɪnz. ðeɪ əsum kəz ə ðəɾ ɪvɛn ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡɹʌdʒ bɪtwin ðə tu wɪmən.

Faile spending time with Berelain, mixed with the formal denunciation of the rumors, was working to convince the camp that nothing inappropriate had happened. Interesting, it seemed that Faile saving Berelain's life during the bubble of evil had had the strongest effect in changing people's minds. They assumed because of that event that there was no grudge between the two women.

ʌv kɔɹs, feɪl hædn seɪv ðə wʊmənz laɪf, dʒʌs hɛlp hɝ. bʌt ðət wɑznt wʌt ðə ɹumɝz sɛd, ən feɪl wɑz pliz tə si ðɛm wɝkɪŋ ɪn əɹ ən pɛɹɪnz feɪvɝ fəɹ wʌns.

Of course, Faile hadn't saved the woman's life, just helped her. But that wasn't what the rumors said, and Faile was pleased to see them working in her and Perrin's favor for once.

ʃi ɹitʃt ðə tɛn ən hɝidli wɑʃt ʌp wɪð ə dæmp klɔθ ən ðɛɹ beɪsən. ʃi pʊɾ ɑn səm pɝfjum, ðən dʒɹɛst ɪn əɹ naɪsɪst ɡaʊn -  ə dɛp ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd vaɪn pæɾɝnz əkɹɔs ðə bɑɾəs ən ɝaʊn ðə hɛm. faɪnəli, ʃi tʃɛk hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ. ɡʊd. ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ əɹ æŋzaɪəɾi. pɛɹɪn wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪt. hi wəd bi.

She reached the tent and hurriedly washed up with a damp cloth and their basin. She put on some perfume, then dressed in her nicest gown -  a depp gray-green with embroidered vine patterns across the bodice and around the hem. Finally, she checked herself in the mirror. Good. She was hiding her anxiety. Perrin would be all right. He would be.

ʃi slɪpt ə fju naɪvz ɪndə hɝ bɛlt ən ʌp əɹ slivz ɛniweɪ. aʊt saɪd, ə ɡɹum hæd bɹɔt deɪlaɪt fəɹ hɝ. ʃi klaɪmd ʌp - mɪsɪŋ swɑloʊ, hu hæd bɪn kɪl baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ivən əɹ faɪnəs dʒɹɛs hæd skɝts dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ; ʃi wʊdn kæɹi ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd tɔɾ əɹ ðət nʌθɪŋ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ə wʊmənz kɹɛɾəbɪlɪti wɪð soʊlʒɝz mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən ɹaɪɾɪŋ saɪdsɑɾəl. ænd, ʃəd ði ənθɪŋkəbəl hæpən ən pɛɹɪn fɔl, feɪl maɪt nid tə teɪk kəmæn ə ðɛɹ fɔɹsɪz.

She slipped a few knives into her belt and up her sleeves anyway. Out side, a groom had brought Daylight for her. She climbed up - missing Swallow, who had been killed by the Shaido. Even her finest dress had skirts divided for riding; she wouldn't carry anything else on the road. Her mother had taught her that nothing destroyed a woman's credibility with soldiers more quickly than riding sidesaddle. And, should the unthinkable happen and Perrin fall, Faile might need to take command of their forces.

ʃi tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɑɹmi. pɛɹɪn sæɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ðɛɹ. haʊ dɛɹ i lʊk soʊ peɪʃənt!

She trotted up to the front of the gathering army. Perrin sat in his saddle there. How dare he look so patient!

feɪl dɪdn lɛɾ əɹ ənɔɪəns ʃoʊ. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪm tə bi ə tɛmpəst ən ə taɪm tə bi ə tɛndɝ bɹiz. ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɛt pɛɹɪn noʊ, ɪn noʊ ənsɝɾən tɝmz, wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ʃi niɾəd tə bi sin səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɪm.

Faile didn't let her annoyance show. There was a time to be a tempest and a time to be a tender breeze. She had already let Perrin know, in no uncertain terms, what she thought of this trial. For the moment, she needed to be seen supporting him.

ʃi ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪnd, wɔkɪŋ laɪk ðə waɪz wʌnz. noʊ meɪɾənz. wɛɹ wɝ ðeɪ? ɪt mʌs bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə kip əm fɹəm ðə tʃɹaɪəl. tə səlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz, pɹətɛktɪŋ pɛɹɪn wɑz ə duɾi ɡɪvən əm baɪ ðɛɹ kɑɹəkɑɹn, ən ɪt wəd bi ə ɡɹeɪv mæɾɝ ə toʊ tə ðɛm ɪf i fɛl.

She rode up beside Perrin as the Aes Sedai gathered behind, walking like the Wise Ones. No Maidens. Where were they? It must be important to keep them from the trial. To Sulin and the others, protecting Perrin was a duty given them by their Car'a'carn, and it would be a grave matter of toh to them if he fell.

skænɪŋ ðə kæmp, ʃi noʊɾəd tu ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪn hʊɾɪd waɪt ɹoʊbz hɝiɪŋ tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə laɪn.

Scanning the camp, she noted two gai'shain in hooded white robes hurrying to the front of the line.

ɡɔl, hu stʊd bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪnz hɔɹs, skaʊld. wʌn ə ðə fɪɡjɝz baʊd tə hɪm, hoʊldɪŋ fɔɹθ ə kəlɛkʃən ə spɪɹz. "fɹɛʃli ʃɑɹpənd," kiæd sɛd.

Gaul, who stood beside Perrin's horse, scowled. One of the figures bowed to him, holding forth a collection of spears. "Freshly sharpened," Chiad said.

"ænd nuli flɛtʃt æɹoʊz," beɪn æɾəd.

"And newly fletched arrows," Bain added.

"aɪ hæv æɹoʊz ən spɪɹz ɔlɹɛɾi," ɡɔl sɛd.

"I have arrows and spears already," Gaul said.

"jɛs," ðə wɪmən sɛd, nilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɪm, stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ ɔfɝɪŋz.

"Yes," the women said, kneeling before him, still holding their offerings.

"wʌt?" hi æskt.

"What?" he asked.

"wi wɝ sɪmpli wɝid fəɹ jəɹ seɪfti," beɪn sɛd. "ju pɹipɛɹd ðoʊz wɛpənz jɝsɛlf, æftɝ ɔl." ʃi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɝnəsli, noʊ hɪn ə mɑkɝi əɹ ɪnsənsɛɹəɾi. jɛt ðə wɝdz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ kloʊs tə peɪtʃɹənaɪzɪŋ.

"We were simply worried for your safety," Bain said. "You prepared those weapons yourself, after all." She said it earnestly, no hint of mockery or insincerity. Yet the words themselves were close to patronizing.

ɡɔl stɑɹɾəd læfɪŋ. hi tʊk ðə wɛpənz ɔfɝɾ ən ɡeɪv ðə wɪmən ɪz oʊn. dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ə ðə deɪ, feɪl faʊn hɝsɛlf smaɪlɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz ə diviəs kəmplɛksəɾi tə il ɪntɝækʃənz.

Gaul started laughing. He took the weapons offered and gave the women his own. Despite the troubles of the day, Faile found herself smiling. There was a devious complexity to Aiel interactions.

wʌt ʃʊɾə plizd ɡɔl ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz ɡeɪʃeɪn ɔfən sim tə fɹʌstʃɹeɪt hɪm, ən jɛt ðət wɪtʃ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnsʌltɪŋ wɑz mɛt wɪð əmjuzmənt.

What should have pleased Gaul regarding his gai'shain often seemed to frustrate him, and yet that which should have been insulting was met with amusement.

əz beɪn ən kiæd ɹitʃɹiɾəd, feɪl lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɑɹmi. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz kʌmɪŋ, nɑt dʒʌs kæptənz əɹ toʊkən fɔɹsɪz. moʊst wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə wɑtʃ ðə tʃɹaɪəl, bʌt ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi ðɛɹ. ɪn keɪs.

As Bain and Chiad retreated, Faile looked over the gathering army. Everyone was coming, not just captains or token forces. Most wouldn't be able to watch the trial, but they needed to be there. In case.

feɪl pʊld ʌp bɪsaɪɾ əɹ hʌzbənd. "sʌmθɪŋ wɝiz ju," ʃi sɛd tə hɪm.

Faile pulled up beside her husband. "Something worries you," she said to him.

"ðə wɝl hoʊlz ɪts bɹɛθ, feɪl," hi sɛd. "wʌt dʒju min?"

"The world holds its breath, Faile," he said. "What do you mean?"

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðə læs hʌn ɪz hɪɹ. ɹænd ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ. mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌv ʌs, hiz ɪn deɪnʒɝ.

He shook his head. "The Last Hunt is here. Rand is in danger. More than any of us, he is in danger.

ən aɪ kænt ɡoʊ tə hɪm, nɑt jɛt."

And I can't go to him, not yet."

"pɛɹɪn, jəɹ nɑt meɪkɪŋ ɛni sɛns. haʊ kən jə noʊ ɹænd ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ?"

"Perrin, you're not making any sense. How can you know Rand is in danger?"

"aɪ kən si hɪm. ɛni taɪm aɪ mɛnʃən ɪz neɪm əɹ θɪŋk ɑn hɪm, ə vɪʒən ə hɪm oʊpənz tə maɪ aɪz."

"I can see him. Any time I mention his name or think on him, a vision of him opens to my eyes."

ʃi blɪŋkt.

She blinked.

hi tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ, hɪz jɛloʊ aɪz θɔtfəl. "aɪm kənɛktəd tə hɪm. hi . .  pʊlz ət mi, jə si. ɛniweɪ, aɪ toʊl maɪsɛlf aɪ wɑz gɑnə bi oʊpən wɪð jə əbaʊt θɪŋz laɪk ðɪs." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "maɪ ɑɹmiz hɪɹ, ðəɹ biɪŋ hɝɾɪd, feɪl. laɪk ʃip biɪŋ dʒɹɪvən tə ðə bʊtʃɝ."

He turned toward her, his yellow eyes thoughtful. "I'm connected to him. He . .  pulls at me, you see. Anyway, I told myself I was going to be open with you about things like this." He hesitated. "My armies here, they're being herded, Faile. Like sheep being driven to the butcher."

hi sʌɾənli ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪz vɪʒən fɹəm ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ʃip ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʊlvz. hid θɔt hɪmsɛlf wʌn ə ðə wʊlvz. bʌt kəɾ i hæv bɪn ɹɔŋ?

He suddenly remembered his vision from the wolf dream. Sheep running in front of wolves. He'd thought himself one of the wolves. But could he have been wrong?

laɪt! hi hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðæt. hi nu wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt, naʊ. "aɪ kən fil ɪɾ ɑn ðə wɪnd," hi sɛd. "ðə pɹɑbləm wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz, ɪts ɹɪleɪɾɪd tə sʌmθɪŋ hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. sʌmbɑɾi wɑns əs tə bi əneɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp ðɪs pleɪs."

Light! He had been wrong about that. He knew what it meant, now. "I can feel it on the wind," he said. "The problem with gateways, it's related to something happening in the wolf dream. Somebody wants us to be unable to escape this place."

ə koʊl bɹiz, ɑɾ ɪn ðə nundeɪ hit, wɑʃt oʊvɝ ðɛm. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?" feɪl æskt.

A cold breeze, odd in the noonday heat, washed over them. "Are you certain?" Faile asked.

"jɛs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɑdli, aɪ æm."

"Yes," Perrin said. "Oddly, I am."

"ðæts wɛɹ ðə meɪɾənz ɑɹ? skaʊɾɪŋ?"

"That's where the Maidens are? Scouting?"

"sʌmwʌn wɑns tə tʃɹæp əs ən ətæk. meɪks moʊst sɛns tə lɛɾ əs klæʃ wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks, ðən kɪl huɛvɝ sɝvaɪvz. bʌt ðət wəd ɹikwaɪɝ ən ɑɹmi, ʌv wɪtʃ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ saɪn. dʒʌst əs ən ðə waɪtkloʊks. aɪ hæv ɛlaɪəs hʌntɪŋ aʊt saɪnz ʌv ə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹiə, bʌɾ i hæzən faʊn ɛniθɪŋ jɛt.

"Someone wants to trap us and attack. Makes most sense to let us clash with the Whitecloaks, then kill whoever survives. But that would require an army, of which there is no sign. Just us and the Whitecloaks. I have Elyas hunting out signs of a Waygate in the area, but he hasn't found anything yet.

soʊ meɪbi ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ, ən aɪm dʒʌs dʒʌmpɪŋ ət ʃædoʊz."

So maybe there's nothing, and I'm just jumping at shadows."

"leɪtli, hʌzbənd, ɪts bɪkʌm laɪkli ðət ðoʊz ʃædoʊz kən baɪt. aɪ tʃɹʌs jəɹ ɪnstɪŋks."

"Lately, husband, it's become likely that those shadows can bite. I trust your instincts."

hi lʊk tə hɝ, ðən smaɪl dipli. "θæŋk ju."

He looked to her, then smiled deeply. "Thank you."

"soʊ wʌt də wi du?"

"So what do we do?"

"wi ɹaɪd tə ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn də wʌtɛvɝ wi kən tə kip fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ tə bæɾəl wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks. ðən tənaɪt, aɪ si ɪf aɪ kən stɑp ðə θɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz pɹɪvɛntɪŋ ðə ɡeɪtweɪz. wi kæn dʒʌst ɹaɪd fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ tə ɪskeɪp ɪt; ðə θɪŋ kən bi muvd. aɪ sɔ ɪɾ ɪn tu pleɪsəz. əl əv tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt, sʌmhaʊ. æftɝ ðæt, wi ɪskeɪp."

"We ride to this trial," Perrin said. "And do whatever we can to keep from going to battle with the Whitecloaks. Then tonight, I see if I can stop the thing that is preventing the gateways. We can't just ride far enough away to escape it; the thing can be moved. I saw it in two places. I'll have to destroy it, somehow. After that, we escape."

ʃi nɑɾəd, ən pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ðə kɔl tə mɑɹtʃ. ðoʊ ðə fɔɹs bɪhaɪn stɪl sim keɪɑɾɪk - laɪk ə ɹoʊp tʃæt hæd bɪn tæŋɡəld - ði ɑɹmi bɪɡæn tə muv. ðə vɛɹiəs ɡɹups sɔɹɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz aʊt, ənɹævəlɪŋ.

She nodded, and Perrin gave the call to march. Though the force behind still seemed chaotic - like a rope chat had been tangled - the army began to move. The various groups sorted themselves out, unraveling.

ðeɪ meɪd ðə ʃɔɹt tʃɹɪp daʊn ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə fild wɪð ðə pəvɪljən. ðə waɪtkloʊks hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɝaɪvd; ðeɪ wɝ ɪn fɔɹmeɪʃən. ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪd bɹɔt ðɛɹ ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi əz wɛl.

They made the short trip down the Jehannah Road, approaching the field with the pavilion. The Whitecloaks had already arrived; they were in formation. It looked as if they'd brought their entire army as well.

ðɪs wɑz gɑnə bi ə tɛns æftɝnun.

This was going to be a tense afternoon.

ɡɔl ɹæn bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪnz hɔɹs, ən i dɪdn sim wɝid, nɔɹ dɪɾ i hæv ɪz feɪs veɪld. feɪl nu hi θɔɾ ɪɾ ɑnɝəbəl fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə ɡoʊ tə tʃɹaɪəl. pɛɹɪn iðɝ hæd tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf əɹ ədmɪt toʊ ən æksɛp dʒʌdʒmənt. il hæd wɔk fɹili tə ðɛɹ oʊn ɛksəkjuʃənz tə mit toʊ.

Gaul ran beside Perrin's horse, and he didn't seem worried, nor did he have his face veiled. Faile knew he thought it honorable for Perrin to go to trial. Perrin either had to defend himself or admit toh and accept judgment. Aiel had walked freely to their own executions to meet toh.

ðeɪ ɹoʊd daʊn tə ðə pəvɪljən. ə tʃɛɹ hæd bɪn sɛɾ ɑn ə loʊ plætfɔɹm ət ðə nɔɹðɝn ɛnd, ɪts bæk tə ðə dɪstən fɔɹəst ə lɛðɝlif. mɔɹ-ɡeɪz sæɾ ɪn ði ɛləveɪɾɪd tʃɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə mɑnɑɹk, wɛɹɪŋ ə ɡaʊn ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊl ðət ɡɑləd mʌst əv faʊn fəɹ hɝ. haʊ hæd feɪl ɛvɝ mɪsteɪkən ðɪs wʊmən fəɹ ə sɪmpəl leɪɾiz meɪd?

They rode down to the pavilion. A chair had been set on a low platform at the northern end, its back to the distant forest of leatherleaf. Mor-gase sat in the elevated chair, looking every inch a monarch, wearing a gown of red and gold that Galad must have found for her. How had Faile ever mistaken this woman for a simple lady's maid?

tʃɛɹz hæd bɪn pleɪst ɪn fɹʌn ə mɔɹɡeɪs, ən waɪtkloʊks fɪl hæf ə ðɛm. ɡɑləd stʊd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ meɪkʃɪf θɹoʊn ə dʒʌdʒmənt. hɪz ɛvɹi lɑk ə hɛɹ wɑz ɪn pleɪs, hɪz junəfɔɹm wɪθaʊt blɛmɪʃ, hɪz kloʊk fɔlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. feɪl ɡlæns tə ðə saɪɾ ən kɑt bɹəleɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət ɡɑləɾ ən blʌʃɪŋ, lʊkɪŋ ɔlmoʊs hʌŋɡɹi. ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ʌp ɑn əɹ ətɛmps tə pɝsweɪd pɛɹɪn tə lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ meɪk pis wɪð ðə waɪtkloʊks.

Chairs had been placed in front of Morgase, and Whitecloaks filled half of them. Galad stood beside her makeshift throne of judgment. His every lock of hair was in place, his uniform without blemish, his cloak falling behind him. Faile glanced to the side and caught Berelain staring at Galad and blushing, looking almost hungry. She had not given up on her attempts to persuade Perrin to let her go make peace with the Whitecloaks.

"ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd," pɛɹɪn kɔld, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə pəvɪljən. feɪl dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən wɔk bɪsaɪd hɪm. "aɪ wɑn jə tə pɹɑməs mi sʌmθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðɪs bɪɡɪnz."

"Galad Damodred," Perrin called, dismounting before the pavilion. Faile dismounted and walked beside him. "I want you to promise me something before this begins."

"ænd wʌt wəd ðət bi?" ðə jʌŋ kəmændɝ kɔl fɹəm ði oʊpən-saɪɾəd tɛnt.

"And what would that be?" the young commander called from the open-sided tent.

"vaʊ nɑt tə lɛt ðɪs tɝn tə bæɾəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Vow not to let this turn to battle," Perrin said.

"aɪ kəd pɹɑməs ðæt," ɡɑləd sɛd. "bʌt, ʌv kɔɹs, juɾ əv tə pɹɑməs mi ðət jəɹ nɑt gɑnə ɹʌn ɪf ðə dʒʌdʒmən fɔlz əɡɛns ju.

"I could promise that," Galad said. "But, of course, you'd have to promise me that you're not going to run if the judgment falls against you.

pɛɹɪn fɛl saɪlənt. ðən i ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn əpɑn ɪz hæmɝ.

Perrin fell silent. Then he rested his hand upon his hammer.

"nɑt wɪlɪŋ tə pɹɑməs ɪt, aɪ si," ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ ɡɪv jə ðɪs tʃæns kəz maɪ mʌðɝ əz pɝsweɪɾəd mi ðət jə ʃəd bi əlaʊd tə spik ɪn jəɹ dɪfɛns. bʌɾ aɪ wəd sunɝ daɪ ðən əlaʊ ə mæn u hæz mɝɾɝd tʃɪlʒɹən tə wɔk əweɪ əntʃælɪnʒd. ɪf jə də nɑt wɪʃ ðɪs tə tɝn tə bæɾəl, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, ðən pɹɛzən jəɹ dɪfɛns wɛl. iðɝ ðæt, əɹ æksɛpt pʌnɪʃmənt."

"Not willing to promise it, I see," Galad said. "I give you this chance because my mother has persuaded me that you should be allowed to speak in your defense. But I would sooner die than allow a man who has murdered Children to walk away unchallenged. If you do not wish this to turn to battle, Perrin Aybara, then present your defense well. Either that, or accept punishment."

feɪl ɡlænst əɾ əɹ hʌzbənd; hi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ. hi lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə spik ðə ɹɪkwɛstɪd pɹɑməs. ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm.

Faile glanced at her husband; he was frowning. He looked as if he wanted to speak the requested promise. She laid a hand on his arm.

"aɪ ʃəd də ɪt," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "haʊ kən ɛni mæn bi əbʌv ðə lɔ, feɪl? aɪ kɪl ðoʊz mɛn ɪn ændɝ wən mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz kwin. aɪ ʃəɾ əbaɪd baɪ hɝ dʒʌdʒmənt."

"I should do it," he said quietly. "How can any man be above the law, Faile? I killed those men in Andor when Morgase was Queen. I should abide by her judgment."

"æn jəɹ duɾi tə ðə pipəl ə jəɹ ɑɹmi?" ʃi æskt. "jɔɹ duɾi tə ɹænd ən tə ðə læs bæɾəl?" ən tə mi?

"And your duty to the people of your army?" she asked. "Your duty to Rand and to the Last Battle?" And to me?

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. "jɔɹ ɹaɪt." ðɛn, laʊɾɝ, hi kəntɪnjud, "lɛts bi ɑn wɪð ðɪs."

Perrin hesitated, then nodded. "You're right." Then, louder, he continued, "Let's be on with this."

pɛɹɪn stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən, dʒɔɪn ɪmiɾiətli baɪ nild, dænɪl ən ɡɹeɪɾi. ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns meɪd pɛɹɪn fil laɪk ə kaʊɝd; ðə weɪ ðə fɔɹ stʊd meɪɾ ɪɾ ɑbviəs ðət ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə lɛɾɪŋ pɛɹɪn bi teɪkən.

Perrin strode into the pavilion, joined immediately by Neald, Dannil and Grady. Their presence made Perrin feel like a coward; the way the four stood made it obvious that they had no intention of letting Perrin be taken.

wʌt wɑz ə tʃɹaɪəl, ɪf pɛɹɪn wəd nɑɾ əbaɪd baɪ ɪts dɪtɝməneɪʃən? nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə ʃæm.

What was a trial, if Perrin would not abide by its determination? Nothing more than a sham.

ðə waɪtkloʊks wɑtʃt tɛnsli, ðɛɹ ɔfəsɝz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾ ə ðə pəvɪljən, ðɛɹ ɑɹmi ət pɝeɪd ɹɛst. ðeɪ lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə stændɪŋ daʊn dʊɹɪŋ ðə pɹoʊsiɾɪŋz. pɛɹɪnz oʊn fɔɹsɪz -  lɑɹdʒɝ, bʌt lɛs ɔɹɾɝli - ɹɪspɑndɪd baɪ stændɪŋ ət ðə ɹɛɾi ɑpəzət ðə waɪtkloʊks.

The Whitecloaks watched tensely, their officers standing in the shade of the pavilion, their army at parade rest. They looked as if they had no intention of standing down during the proceedings. Perrin's own forces -  larger, but less orderly - responded by standing at the ready opposite the Whitecloaks.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ən ɹoʊən hʌm muvd ɔf tə meɪk sɝɾən ɡɑləd hæd ɹilis ðə kæptɪvz.

Perrin nodded, and Rowan Hum moved off to make certain Galad had released the captives.

pɛɹɪn wɔk tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə pəvɪljən, stɑpɪŋ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ mɔɹɡeɪsəz ɛləveɪɾɪd sit. feɪl steɪd baɪ hɪz saɪd. ðəɹ wɝ tʃɛɹz fəɹ ɪm hɪɹ, ən i sæt. sɛvɹəl stɛps tə hɪz lɛft wɑz mɔɹɡeɪsəz stænd.

Perrin walked to the front of the pavilion, stopping just before Morgase's elevated seat. Faile stayed by his side. There were chairs for him here, and he sat. Several steps to his left was Morgase's stand.

tə hɪz ɹaɪt, ðə pipəl sæt tə wɑtʃ ðə tʃɹaɪəl. hɪz bæk wɑz təwɔɹɾ ɪz ɑɹmi.

To his right, the people sat to watch the trial. His back was toward his army.

feɪl - smɛlɪŋ wɛɹi - sæt nɛks tə hɪm. ʌðɝz faɪld ɪn. bɹəleɪn ən æliændɝ sæt wɪð ðɛɹ ɡɑɹdz nɪɹ hɪm; ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz stʊɾ ət ðə bæk, ɹəfjuzɪŋ sits. ðə læs fju sits wɝ teɪkən baɪ ə fju ʌv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ən səm ə ðə sinjɝ fɔɹmɝ ɹɛfjudʒiz.

Faile - smelling wary - sat next to him. Others filed in. Berelain and Alliandre sat with their guards near him; the Aes Sedai and Wise Ones stood at the back, refusing seats. The last few seats were taken by a few of the Two Rivers men and some of the senior former refugees.

ðə waɪtkloʊk ɔfəsɝz sæt daʊn ɑpəzət ðɛm, feɪsɪŋ feɪl ən pɛɹɪn. bɔɹnhəld ən baɪɑɝ ət ðə fɹʌnt. ðəɹ wɝ əbaʊt θɝɾi tʃɛɹz, laɪkli teɪkən fɹəm pɛɹɪnz səplaɪz ðət ðə waɪtkloʊks hæɾ əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd.

The Whitecloak officers sat down opposite them, facing Faile and Perrin. Bornhald and Byar at the front. There were about thirty chairs, likely taken from Perrin's supplies that the Whitecloaks had appropriated.

pɛɹɪn," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd fɹəm əɹ sit. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jə wɑnə ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð ðɪs?"

Perrin," Morgase said from her seat. "Are you certain you want to go through with this?"

"aɪ æm," hi sɛd.

"I am," he said.

vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛd, hɝ feɪs ɪmpæsɪv, ðoʊ ʃi smɛl hɛzɪɾənt. ə fɔɹməli bɪɡɪn ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl.

Very well," she said, her face impassive, though she smelled hesitant. A formally begin this trial.

ði əkjuzd ɪz pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, noʊn əz pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "lɔɹɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," ʃi æɾəd. "ɡɑləd, jəl pɹizɛn ðə tʃɑɹdʒəz."

The accused is Perrin Aybara, known as Perrin Goldeneyes." She hesitated. "Lord of the Two Rivers," she added. "Galad, you will present the charges."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ θɹi," ɡɑləd sɛd, stændɪŋ. "ðə fɝs tu ɑɹ ði ənlɔfəl mɝɾɝ ə tʃaɪld læðən ən ði ənlɔfəl mɝɾɝ ə tʃaɪl jæmwɪk. eɪ-bɑɹə ɪz ɔlsoʊ əkjuzd ə biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛn ən ə bɹɪŋɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

"There are three," Galad said, standing. "The first two are the unlawful murder of Child Lathin and the unlawful murder of Child Yamwick. Ay-bara is also accused of being a Darkfriend and of bringing Trollocs into the Two Rivers."

ðəɹ wɝ æŋɡɹi mɝmɝz fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ət ðət wʌnæs tʃɑɹdʒ. ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks hæd kɪl pɛɹɪnz oʊn fæmli.

There were angry murmurs from the Two Rivers men at that 1ast charge. Those Trollocs had killed Perrin's own family.

ɡɑləd kəntɪnjud, "ðə læs tʃɑɹdʒ kænɑt bi səbstænʃieɪɾɪd jɛt, əz maɪ mɛn wɝ fɔɹst aʊɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd ɡæðɝ pɹuf, əz tə ðə fɝs tu tʃɑɹdʒəz, eɪbɑɹə hæz ɔlɹɛɾi ədmɪɾəd ɪz ɡɪlt."

Galad continued, "The last charge cannot be substantiated yet, as my men were forced out of the Two Rivers before they could gather proof, As to the first two charges, Aybara has already admitted his guilt."

"ɪz ðɪs soʊ, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə?" mɔɹɡeɪs æskt.

"Is this so, Lord Aybara?" Morgase asked.

"aɪ kɪl ðoʊz mɛn, ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn mɝɾɝ"

"I killed those men, sure enough," Perrin said. "But it wasn't murder"

"ðɛn ðɪs ɪz wʌt ðə kɔɹt wɪl dətɝmən," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd fɔɹməli. "æn ðɪs ɪz ðə dɪspjut."

"Then this is what the court will determine," Morgase said formally. "And this is the dispute."

mɔɹɡeɪs simd ə kəmplitli dɪfɹən pɝsən fɹəm meɪaɪɡdɪn. wɑz ðɪs haʊ pipəl ɪkspɛktəd pɛɹɪn tə ækt wən ðeɪ keɪm tə hɪm fəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt? hi hæd tə ədmɪt, ʃi dɪd lɛn ðə pɹoʊsiɾɪŋz ə mɛʒɝ ə niɾəd fɔɹmæləɾi. æftɝ ɔl, ðə tʃɹaɪəl wɑz hæpənɪŋ ɪn ə tɛn ɑn ə fild wɪð ðə dʒʌdʒəz tʃɛɹ ɛləveɪɾɪd baɪ wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə smɔl stæk ə bɑksəz wɪð ə ɹʌɡ θɹoʊn oʊvɝ ðɛm.

Morgase seemed a completely different person from Maighdin. Was this how people expected Perrin to act when they came to him for judgment? He had to admit, she did lend the proceedings a measure of needed formality. After all, the trial was happening in a tent on a field with the judge's chair elevated by what appeared to be a small stack of boxes with a rug thrown over them.

"ɡɑləd," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "jɔɹ mɛn meɪ tɛl ðɛɹ saɪɾ ə ðə stɔɹi."

"Galad," Morgase said. "Your men may tell their side of the story."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd tə baɪɑɝ. hi stʊd, ən ənʌðɝ waɪtkloʊk - ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð ə kəmplitli bɔl hɛd - stɛp fɔɹwɝd tə dʒɔɪn hɪm. bɔɹnhəld ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd.

Galad nodded to Byar. He stood, and another Whitecloak - a young man with a completely bald head - stepped forward to join him. Bornhald remained seated.

"jɔɹ ɡɹeɪs," baɪɑɝ sɛd, "ɪt hæpən əbaʊt tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ. dʊɹɪŋ ðə spɹɪŋ. ən ənnətʃɝəli koʊl spɹɪŋ, aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ. wi wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ bæk fɹəm ɪmpɔɹɾənt bɪznəs ət ðə kəmæn ə ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, ən wi wɝ pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə wɪldɝnəs ə sɛntʃɹəl ændɝ. wi wɝ gɑnə kæmp fəɹ ðə naɪɾ əɾ ən əbændən oʊɡiɝ stɛɾɪŋ, ət ðə beɪs ʌv wʌt wɑz wʌns ən ɪnɔɹməs stætʃu. ðə kaɪndə pleɪs jə əsum wɪl bi seɪf."

"Your Grace," Byar said, "it happened about two years ago. During the spring. An unnaturally cold spring, I remember. We were on our way back from important business at the command of the Lord Captain Commander, and we were passing through the wilderness of central Andor. We were going to camp for the night at an abandoned Ogier stedding, at the base of what was once an enormous statue. The kind of place you assume will be safe."

pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət naɪt. ə tʃɪl ist wɪn bloʊɪŋ əkɹɔs hɪm, ɹʌfəlɪŋ ɪz kloʊk əz i stʊd baɪ ə pul ə fɹɛʃ wɔɾɝ. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə sʌn daɪɪŋ saɪlənli ɪn ðə wɛst. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə pul ɪn ðə weɪnɪŋ laɪt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wɪn ɹʌfəl ɪts sɝfəs, hoʊldɪŋ ði æks ɪn ɪz hænz.

Perrin remembered that night. A chill east wind blowing across him, ruffling his cloak as he stood by a pool of fresh water. He remembered the sun dying silently in the west. He remembered staring at the pool in the waning light, watching the wind ruffle its surface, holding the axe in his hands.

ðət blæstəɾ æks. hi ʃʊɾə θɹoʊn ɪɾ əweɪ ɹaɪt ðɛn. ɛlaɪəs hæd pɝsweɪɾəd ɪm tə kip ɪt.

That blasted axe. He should have thrown it away right then. Elyas had persuaded him to keep it.

"wɛn wi ɝaɪvd," baɪɑɝ kəntɪnjud, "wi faʊn ðət ðə kæmpsaɪt hæd bɪn juzd ɹisənli. ðət kənsɝn ʌs; fju pipəl nu ʌv ðə stɛɾɪŋ- wi dɪtɝmənd, fɹəm ðə sɪŋɡəl faɪɹɛpɪt, ðət ðəɹ wɝ nɑt mɛni ʌv ðiz mɪstɪɹiəs weɪfɛɹɝz."

"When we arrived," Byar continued, "we found that the campsite had been used recently. That concerned us; few people knew of the stedding- We determined, from the single firepit, that there were not many of these mysterious wayfarers."

hɪz vɔɪs wɑz pɹɪsaɪs, hɪz dɪskɹɪpʃən məθɑɾəkəl. ðət wɑzn haʊ pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə naɪt.

His voice was precise, his description methodical. That wasn't how Perrin remembered the night.

noʊ, hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə hɪs ə ðə fleɪmz, spɑɹks flʌɾɝɪŋ æŋɡɹəli ɪndə ði ɛɹ əz ɛlaɪəs dʌmp ðə tipəts kɑntɛns ɪn tə faɪɹɛpɪt. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə heɪsti sɛndɪŋ fɹəm ðə wʊlvz flʌɾɪŋ ɪz maɪnd, kənfjuzɪŋ hɪm. ðə wʊlvz' wɛɹinɪs hæd meɪɾ ɪt hɑɹd tə sɛpɝeɪt hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ðɛm. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə smɛl ə fɪɹ ɑn ɛɡwin, ðə weɪ hi fʌmbəld wɪð bɛləz sæɾəl əz i sɪntʃt ɪt. ən i ɹɪmɛmbɝd hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn u smɛld ɹɔŋ. laɪk ðə waɪtkloʊks ɪn ðə pəvɪljən. ðeɪ smɛld laɪk sɪk wʊlvz u snæpt əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət ɡɑt tu kloʊz. "ðə lɔɹd kæptən wɑz wɝid," baɪɑɝ kəntɪnjud. hi wɑz ɑbviəsli nɑt mɛnʃənɪŋ ðə kæptənz neɪm, pɝhæps tə spɛɹ bɔɹnhəld. ðə jʌŋ waɪtkloʊk kæptən sæt pɝfəkli stɪl, stɛɹɪŋ ət baɪɑɝ əz ɪf i dɪdn tʃɹʌs hɪmsɛlf tə lʊk ət pɛɹɪn. "hi θɔt ðət meɪbi ðə kæmp hæd bɪn juz baɪ bɹɪɡænz. hu ɛls wəd daʊs ðɛɹ faɪɝ ən vænɪʃ ðə moʊmən sʌmwʌn ɛls əpɹoʊtʃt? ðæts wən wi sɔ ðə fɝst wʊlf."

No, he remembered the hiss of the flames, sparks fluttering angrily into the air as Elyas dumped the teapots contents int to firepit. He remembered a hasty sending from the wolves flooding his mind, confusing him. The wolves' wariness had made it hard to separate himself from them. He remembered the smell of fear on Egwene, the way he fumbled with Bela's saddle as he cinched it. And he remembered hundreds of men who smelled wrong. Like the Whitecloaks in the pavilion. They smelled like sick wolves who snapped at anything that got too close. "The Lord Captain was worried," Byar continued. He was obviously not mentioning the captain's name, perhaps to spare Bornhald. The young Whitecloak captain sat perfectly still, staring at Byar as if he didn't trust himself to look at Perrin. "He thought that maybe the camp had been used by brigands. Who else would douse their fire and vanish the moment someone else approached? That's when we saw the first wolf."

haɪɾɪŋ, bɹɛθ kʌmɪŋ ɪn kwɪk ʃɔɹt ɡæsps, ɛɡwin hʌɾəld bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ðə sɛn ə kæmpfaɪɝ smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm əɹ kloʊðɪŋ ən fɹəm hɪz. bɛlə bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ðə ʃɛltɝɪŋ kɑnfaɪnz ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs stoʊn hænd, ðə hæn ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz stætʃu, wɪtʃ hæd bɹoʊkən fɹi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ.

Hiding, breath coming in quick short gasps, Egwene huddled beside him in the dark. The scent of campfire smoke rising from her clothing and from his. Bela breathing in the darkness. The sheltering confines of an enormous stone hand, the hand of Artur Hawkwing's statue, which had broken free long before.

dæpəl, æŋɡɹi ən wɝid. ɪmədʒəz ə mɛn ɪn waɪt wɪð fleɪmɪŋ tɔɹtʃɪz. wɪnd, dɑɹɾɪŋ bɪtwin ðə tʃɹiz.

Dapple, angry and worried. Images of men in white with flaming torches. Wind, darting between the trees.

"ðə lɔɹd kæptən θɔt ðə wʊlvz wɝ ə bæd saɪn. ɛvɹiwʌn noʊz ðeɪ sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

"The Lord Captain thought the wolves were a bad sign. Everyone knows they serve the Dark One.

hi sɛn əs tə skaʊt. maɪ tim sɝtʃt tə ði ist, lʊkɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃənz ən ʃɑɹdz ə ði ɪnɔɹməs bɹoʊkən stætʃu."

He sent us to scout. My team searched to the east, looking through the rock formations and shards of the enormous broken statue."

peɪn. mɛn ʃaʊɾɪŋ. pɛɹɪn? wɪl jə dæns wɪð mi ət sʌndeɪ? ɪf wɝ hoʊm baɪ ðɛn. . . .

Pain. Men shouting. Perrin? Will you dance with me at Sunday? If we're home by then. . . .

"ðə wʊlvz stɑɹɾəd tə ətæk ʌs," baɪɑɝ sɛd, vɔɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑɹd. "ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ðət ðeɪ wɝ noʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi kɹitʃɝz. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ koʊɔɹɾəneɪʃən tə ðɛɹ əsɔls. ðəɹ sim tə bi dʌzənz ə ðɛm, muvɪŋ θɹu ðə ʃædoʊz. ðəɹ wɝ mɛn əmʌŋ ðɛm, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ən kɪlɪŋ əɹ maʊns."

"The wolves started to attack us," Byar said, voice growing hard. "It was obvious that they were no ordinary creatures. There was too much coordination to their assaults. There seemed to be dozens of them, moving through the shadows. There were men among them, striking and killing our mounts."

pɛɹɪn hæd wɑtʃt ɪt wɪð tu sɛts ʌv aɪz. hɪz oʊn, fɹəm ðə væntədʒ ə ðə hænd. ən ði aɪz ə ðə wʊlvz, hu oʊnli wɑntəd tə bi lɛft əloʊn. ðeɪ hæd bɪn wundəɾ ɝliɝ baɪ ən ɪnɔɹməs flɑk ə ɹeɪvənz. ðeɪd tʃɹaɪd tə dʒɹaɪv ðə mɛn əweɪ. skɛɹ ðɛm.

Perrin had watched it with two sets of eyes. His own, from the vantage of the hand. And the eyes of the wolves, who only wanted to be left alone. They had been wounded earlier by an enormous flock of ravens. They'd tried to drive the men away. Scare them.

soʊ mʌtʃ fɪɹ. boʊθ ðə fɪɹ ə ðə mɛn ən ðə fɪɹ ə ðə wʊlvz. ɪt hæd ɹul ðət naɪt, kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ boʊθ saɪdz. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ faɪɾɪŋ tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪmsɛlf, bɪwɪldɝd baɪ ðə sɛndɪŋz.

So much fear. Both the fear of the men and the fear of the wolves. It had ruled that night, controlling both sides. He could remember fighting to remain himself, bewildered by the sendings.

"ðæt naɪt stʃɹɛtʃt lɔŋ," baɪɑɝ sɛd, vɔɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɑftɝ, jɛt fʊl ʌv æŋɡɝ. "wi pæst ə hɪlsaɪd wɪð ə mæsɪv flæt ɹɑk ət ðə tɑp, ən tʃɪd læðən sɛɾ i θɔɾ i sɔ sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ðɛɹ. wi stɑpt, hoʊldɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ əɹ laɪts, ən sɔ ðə lɛɡz ʌv ə hɔɹs bɪniθ ði oʊvɝhæŋ. aɪ ɡeɪv læðən ə nɑd, ən i stɛp fɔɹwɝd tə ɔɹɾɝ huɛvɝ wɑz ɪn ðəɹ daʊn tə aɪdɛntəfaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz.

"That night stretched long," Byar said, voice growing softer, yet full of anger. "We passed a hillside with a massive flat rock at the top, and Chid Lathin said he thought he saw something in the shadows there. We stopped, holding forward our lights, and saw the legs of a horse beneath the overhang. I gave Lathin a nod, and he stepped forward to order whoever was in there down to identify themselves.

"wɛl, ðət mæn - eɪbɑɹə - keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs wɪð ə jʌŋ wʊmən. hi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ə wɪkəɾ æks, ən i wɔkt kɑmli ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə læðən, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə læns pɔɪntəɾ əɾ ɪz tʃɛst. ən ðɛn.

"Well, that man - Aybara - came out of the darkness with a young woman. He was carrying a wicked axe, and he walked calmly right up to Lathin, ignoring the lance pointed at his chest. And then.

. . ."

. . ."

ən ðən ðə wʊlvz tʊk oʊvɝ. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɪt hæd hæpən tə pɛɹɪn. ðɛɹ sɛndɪŋz hæd bɪn soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət pɛɹɪn hæd lɔs hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ kɹʌʃɪŋ læðənz nɛk wɪð ɪz tiθ, ðə wɔɹm blʌd bɝstɪŋ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ əz ɪf hid bɪɾən ɪndə ə fɹut. ðət mɛmɹi hæd bɪn hɑpɝz, bʌt pɛɹɪn kʊdn sɛpɹət hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ðə wʊlf fəɹ ðə moʊməns ə ðət faɪt.

And then the wolves took over. It was the first time it had happened to Perrin. Their sendings had been so strong that Perrin had lost himself. He could remember crushing Lathin's neck with his teeth, the warm blood bursting into his mouth as if he'd bitten into a fruit. That memory had been Hoppers, but Perrin couldn't separate himself from the wolf for the moments of that fight.

"æn ðɛn?" mɔɹɡeɪs pɹɑmptəd.

"And then?" Morgase prompted.

"æn ðən ðəɹ wɑz ə faɪt," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "wʊlvz lɛp fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ ən eɪbɑɹə ətækt ʌs.

"And then there was a fight," Byar said. "Wolves leaped from the shadow and Aybara attacked us.

hi dɪdn muv laɪk ə mæn, bʌt laɪk ə bist, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ. wi səbduɾ ɪm ən kɪld wʌn ə ðə wʊlvz, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ eɪbɑɹə hæd mænədʒ tə kɪl tu ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən."

He didn't move like a man, but like a beast, growling. We subdued him and killed one of the wolves, but not before Aybara had managed to kill two of the Children."

baɪɑɝ sæt daʊn. mɔɹɡeɪs æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz. ʃi tɝn tə ði ʌðɝ waɪtkloʊk u hæd stʊd wɪð baɪɑɝ.

Byar sat down. Morgase asked no questions. She turned to the other Whitecloak who had stood with Byar.

"aɪ hæv lɪɾəl tə lɛnd," ðə mæn sɛd. "aɪ wɑz ðɛɹ, ən aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɾ ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm weɪ. aɪ wɑnə pɔɪn aʊt ðət wən wi tʊk eɪbɑɹə ɪndə kʌstəɾi, hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dʒʌdʒd ɡɪlti. wi wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə  - "

"I have little to lend," the man said. "I was there, and I remember it exactly the same way. I want to point out that when we took Aybara into custody, he was already judged guilty. We were going to  - "

"ðæt dʒʌdʒmən ɪz ə noʊ kənsɝn tə ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd koʊldli."

"That judgment is of no concern to this trial," Morgase said coldly."

"wɛl, ðɛn, əlaʊ maɪ vɔɪs tə bi ðə tɛstəmoʊni ʌv ə sɛkənd wɪtnəs. aɪ sɔ ɪɾ ɔl, tu." ðə bɔld waɪtkloʊk sæt daʊn.

"Well, then, allow my voice to be the testimony of a second witness. I saw it all, too." The bald Whitecloak sat down.

mɔɹɡeɪs tɝn tə pɛɹɪn. "ju meɪ spik."

Morgase turned to Perrin. "You may speak."

pɛɹɪn stʊɾ ʌp sloʊli. "ðoʊz tu spoʊk tʃɹuli, mɔɹɡeɪs. ðæts əbaʊt haʊ ɪt hæpənd."

Perrin stood up slowly. "Those two spoke truly, Morgase. That's about how it happened."

"əbaʊt?" mɔɹɡeɪs æskt.

"About?" Morgase asked.

"hiz nɪɹli ɹaɪt."

"He's nearly right."

"jɔɹ ɡɪlt əɹ ɪnəsəns hæŋz ɑn ɪz 'nɪɹli,' lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə. ɪts ðə mɛʒɝ baɪ wɪtʃ jəl bi dʒʌdʒd."

"Your guilt or innocence hangs on his 'nearly,' Lord Aybara. It is the measure by which you will be judged."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "ðæɾ ɪt dʌz. tɛl mi sʌmθɪŋ, jəɹ ɡɹeɪs. wən jə dʒʌdʒ sʌmwʌn laɪk ðɪs, dʒju tʃɹaɪ tə ʌndɝstæn ðɛɹ dɪfɹən pisəz?"

Perrin nodded. "That it does. Tell me something, Your Grace. When you judge someone like this, do you try to understand their different pieces?"

ʃi fɹaʊnd. "wʌt?"

She frowned. "What?"

"maɪ mæstɝ, ðə mæn u tʃɹeɪn mi əz ə blæksmɪθ, tɔt mi ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt lɛsən. tə kɹieɪt sʌmθɪŋ, juv tə ʌndɝstæn ɪt. ən tə ʌndɝstæn sʌmθɪŋ, juv tə noʊ wʌɾ ɪts meɪɾ ʌv." ə kul bɹiz blu θɹu ðə pəvɪljən, ɹʌfəlɪŋ kloʊks. ðət mætʃt ðə kwaɪət saʊnz fɹəm ðə pleɪnz aʊtsaɪd  - mɛn ʃɪftɪŋ ɪn ɑɹmɝ ən hɔɹsəz stæmpɪŋ, kɔfs ən oʊkɑʒənəl wɪspɝz əz ɪz wɝdz wɝ pæs θɹu ðə ɹæŋks.

"My master, the man who trained me as a blacksmith, taught me an important lesson. To create something, you have to understand it. And to understand something, you have to know what it is made of." A cool breeze blew through the pavilion, ruffling cloaks. That matched the quiet sounds from the plains outside  - men shifting in armor and horses stamping, coughs and ocasional whispers as his words were passed through the ranks.

"aɪv kʌm tə si sʌmθɪŋ leɪtli," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "mɛn ɑɹ meɪɾ ʌp ʌv ə lɑɾ ə dɪfɹən pisəz.

"I've come to see something lately," Perrin said. "Men are made up of a lot of different pieces.

hu ðeɪ ɑɹ dɪpɛnz ɑn wʌt sɪtʃueɪʃən jə pʊɾ əm ɪn. aɪ hæɾ ə hæn ɪn kɪlɪŋ ðoʊz tu mɛn. bʌt tə ʌndɝstænd, juv tə si ðə pisəz ə mi."

Who they are depends on what situation you put them in. I had a hand in killing those two men. But to understand, you have to see the pieces of me."

hi mɛt ɡɑlədz aɪz. ðə jʌŋ waɪtkloʊk kæptən stʊd wɪð ə stʃɹeɪt bæk, hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. pɛɹɪn wɪʃt i kəd kætʃ ðə mænz sɛnt.

He met Galad's eyes. The young Whitecloak captain stood with a straight back, hands clasped behind his back. Perrin wished he could catch the man's scent.

pɛɹɪn tɝn bæk tə mɔɹɡeɪs. "aɪ kən spik wɪð wʊlvz. aɪ hɪɹ ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz ɪn maɪ maɪnd. aɪ noʊ ðət saʊnz laɪk ði ædmɪʃən ʌv ə mædmæn, bʌɾ aɪ səspɛk ðət mɛni ɪn maɪ kæmp u hɪɹ ɪt woʊn bi sɝpɹaɪzd. ɡɪvən taɪm, aɪ kəd pɹuv ɪt tə ju, wɪð ðə koʊɑpɝeɪʃən ə səm loʊkəl wʊlvz."

Perrin turned back to Morgase. "I can speak with wolves. I hear their voices in my mind. I know that sounds like the admission of a madman, but I suspect that many in my camp who hear it won't be surprised. Given time, I could prove it to you, with the cooperation of some local wolves."

"ðæt woʊn bi nɛsəsɛɹi," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. ʃi smɛld ə fɪɹ. ðə wɪspɝz fɹəm ði ɑɹmiz ɡɹu laʊɾɝ. hi kɑt feɪlz sɛnt. wɝi.

"That won't be necessary," Morgase said. She smelled of fear. The whispers from the armies grew louder. He caught Faile's scent. Worry.

"ðɪs θɪŋ aɪ kən du," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪts ə pis ə mi, dʒʌst əz fɔɹdʒɪŋ aɪɝn ɪz. dʒʌst əz liɾɪŋ mɛn ɪz. ɪf jəɹ gɑnə pæs dʒʌdʒmən ɑn mi kəz ʌv ɪt, jə ʃəɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt."

"This thing I can do," Perrin said. "It's a piece of me, just as forging iron is. Just as leading men is. If you're going to pass judgment on me because of it, you should understand it."

"ju dɪɡ jəɹ oʊn ɡɹeɪv, eɪbɑɹə," bɔɹnhəl sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ən pɔɪntɪŋ. "aʊɝ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ sɛɾ i kəd nɑt pɹuv jə wɝ ə dɑɹk-fɹɛnd, ən jɛt hɪɹ jə meɪk ðə keɪs fəɹ ʌs!"

"You dig your own grave, Aybara," Bornhald said, rising and pointing. "Our Lord Captain Commander said he could not prove you were a Dark-friend, and yet here you make the case for us!"

"ðɪs dʌzn meɪk mi ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"This doesn't make me a Darkfriend," Perrin said.

"ðə pɝpəs ə ðɪs kɔɹt," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd fɝmli, "ɪz nɑt tə dʒʌdʒ ðəɾ æləɡeɪʃən. wɪl dətɝmən eɪbɑɹəz kʌlpəbɪlɪɾi fəɹ ðə dɛθs ə ðoʊz tu mɛn, ən nʌθɪŋ ɛls. jə meɪ sɪt, tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld."

"The purpose of this court," Morgase said firmly, "is not to judge that allegation. We will determine Aybara's culpability for the deaths of those two men, and nothing else. You may sit, Child Bornhald."

bɔɹnhəl sæɾ æŋɡɹəli.

Bornhald sat angrily.

"aɪ hæv jɛt tə hɪɹ jəɹ dɪfɛns, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd.

"I have yet to hear your defense, Lord Aybara," Morgase said.

"ðə ɹizən aɪ toʊl jə wʌɾ aɪm - wʌɾ aɪ də - ɪz tə ʃoʊ jə ðət ðə wʊlvz wɝ maɪ fɹɛnz."

"The reason I told you what I am - what I do - is to show you that the wolves were my friends."

hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ðæt naɪɾ ɪn ændɝ . . . ɪt wɑz tɛɹəbəl, əz baɪɑɝ sɛd. wi wɝ skɛɹd, ɔl ʌv ʌs. ðə waɪtkloʊks wɝ skɛɹɾ ə ðə wʊlvz, ðə wʊlvz wɝ skɛɹɾ ə ðə faɪɝ ən ðə θɹɛɾənɪŋ moʊʃənz ðə mɛn meɪd, ən aɪ wɑz pleɪn skɛɹɾ ə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn mi. aɪd nɛvɝ bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz bɪfɔɹ, ən dɪdn ʌndɝstænd waɪ aɪ hɝd wʊlvz ɪn maɪ hɛd.

He took a deep breath. "That night in Andor . . . it was terrible, as Byar said. We were scared, all of us. The Whitecloaks were scared of the wolves, the wolves were scared of the fire and the threatening motions the men made, and I was plain scared of the world around me. I'd never been out of the Two Rivers before, and didn't understand why I heard wolves in my head.

wɛl, nʌn ə ðəɾ ɪz ən ɪkskjus, ən aɪ doʊn min ɪt tə bi wʌn. aɪ kɪl ðoʊz mɛn, bʌt ðeɪ ətæk maɪ fɹɛnz. wən ðə mɛn wɛn hʌntɪŋ fəɹ wʊlf pɛls, ðə wʊlvz fɔt bæk." hi stɑpt. ðeɪ niɾəd ðə hoʊl tʃɹuθ. "tə bi ɑnəst, jəɹ ɡɹeɪs, aɪ wɑzn ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə maɪsɛlf. aɪ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə sɝɛndɝ. bʌt wɪð ðə wʊlvz ɪn maɪ hɛd. ... aɪ fɛl ðɛɹ peɪn. ðən ðə waɪtkloʊks kɪld ə dɪɹ fɹɛn ə maɪn, ən aɪ hæd tə faɪt. aɪd də ðə seɪm θɪŋ tə pɹətɛkt ə fɑɹmɝ biɪŋ hɝæs baɪ soʊlʒɝz."

Well, none of that is an excuse, and I don't mean it to be one. I killed those men, but they attacked my friends. When the men went hunting for wolf pelts, the wolves fought back." He stopped. They needed the whole truth. "To be honest, Your Grace, I wasn't in control of myself. I was ready to surrender. But with the wolves in my head. ... I felt their pain. Then the Whitecloaks killed a dear friend of mine, and I had to fight. I'd do the same thing to protect a farmer being harassed by soldiers."

"jɔɹ ə kɹitʃɝ ə ðə ʃædoʊ!" bɔɹnhəl sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ əɡɛn. "jɔɹ laɪz ɪnsʌl ðə dɛd!"

"You're a creature of the Shadow!" Bornhald said, rising again. "Your lies insult the dead!"

pɛɹɪn tɝn təwɔɹd ðə mæn, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ðə tɛn fɛl saɪlənt, ən pɛɹɪn kəd smɛl ðə tɛnʃən hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. "hæv jə nɛvɝ ɹeɪ-ælɪz ðət səm mɛn ɑɹ dɪfɹən fɹəm ju, bɔɹnhəld?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "hæv jə ɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk wʌɾ ɪt mʌs bi laɪk tə bi sʌmwʌn ɛls? ɪf jə kəd si θɹu ðiz ɡoʊldən aɪz ə maɪn, jud faɪn ðə wɝld ə dɪfɹən pleɪs."

Perrin turned toward the man, holding his eyes. The tent fell silent, and Perrin could smell the tension hanging in the air. "Have you never re-alized that some men are different from you, Bornhald?" Perrin asked. "Have you ever tried to think what it must be like to be someone else? If you could see through these golden eyes of mine, you'd find the world a different place."

bɔɹnhəld oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əz ɪf tə spɪɾ aʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɪnsəlt, bʌt lɪkt ɪz lɪps, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɡɹoʊn dʒɹaɪ. "ju mɝɾɝd maɪ fɑðɝ," hi faɪnəli sɛd.

Bornhald opened his mouth as if to spit out another insult, but licked his lips, as if they had grown dry. "You murdered my father," he finally said.

"ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ hæd bɪn bloʊn," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn fɔɾ ɪʃəml ɪn ðə skaɪ. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðiz ʃɔɹz tə dɑməneɪt. jɛs, aɪ wɑz ɪn fɑlm. aɪ ɹoʊd tə bæɾəl əlɔŋsaɪd ðə hɪɹoʊz ə ðə hɔɹn, əlɔŋsaɪd hɔkwɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, faɪɾɪŋ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. aɪ fɔɾ ɑn ðə seɪm saɪɾ əz jəɹ fɑðɝ, bɔɹnhəld. aɪv sɛd ðəɾ i wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn, ən i wɑz. hi tʃɑɹdʒ bɹeɪvli. hi daɪd bɹeɪvli."

"The Horn of Valere had been blown," Perrin said, "the Dragon Reborn fought Ishamael in the sky. Artur Hawkwing's armies had returned to these shores to dominate. Yes, I was in Falme. I rode to battle alongside the heroes of the Horn, alongside Hawkwing himself, fighting against the Seanchan. I fought on the same side as your father, Bornhald. I've said that he was a good man, and he was. He charged bravely. He died bravely."

ði ɑɾiəns wɑz soʊ stɪl ðeɪ sim stætʃuz. nɑɾ ə wʌn muvd. bɔɹnhəld oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə əbdʒɛkt əɡɛn, bʌt ðən kloʊzd ɪt.

The audience was so still they seemed statues. Not a one moved. Bornhald opened his mouth to object again, but then closed it.

"aɪ swɛɹ tə ju," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ maɪ hoʊp ə sælveɪʃən ən ɹibɝθ, ðəɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt kɪl jəɹ fɑðɝ. nɔɹ hæɾ aɪ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz dɛθ."

"I swear to you," Perrin said, "under the Light and by my hope of salvation and rebirth, that I did not kill your father. Nor had I anything to do with his death."

bɔɹnhəl sɝtʃt pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən lʊk tʃɹʌbəld.

Bornhald searched Perrin's eyes, and looked troubled.

"doʊn lɪsən tə hɪm, deɪn," baɪɑɝ sɛd. ðə sɛn ə hɪm wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ ɪn ðə pəvɪljən. fɹɛnzid, laɪk ɹɑɾən mit. "hi dɪd kɪl jəɹ fɑðɝ."

"Don't listen to him, Dain," Byar said. The scent of him was strong, stronger than any other in the pavilion. Frenzied, like rotten meat. "He did kill your father."

ɡɑləd stɪl stʊd, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ. "aɪv nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd haʊ jə noʊ ðɪs, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ.

Galad still stood, watching the exchange. "I've never understood how you know this, Child Byar.

wʌd jə si? pɝhæps ðɪs ʃəd bi ðə tʃɹaɪəl wi hoʊld."

What did you see? Perhaps this should be the trial we hold."

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt wʌɾ aɪ sɔ, lɔɹd kæptən," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "bʌt wʌɾ aɪ noʊ. haʊ ɛls kən jə ɪkspleɪn haʊ hi sɝvaɪvd, jɛt ðə lidʒən dɪd nɑt! jəɹ fɑðɝ wɑz ə væljənt wɔɹiɝ, bɔɹnhəld. hi wəd nɛvɝ əv fɔlən tə ðə sintʃæn!"

"It is not what I saw, Lord Captain," Byar said. "But what I know. How else can you explain how he survived, yet the legion did not! Your father was a valiant warrior, Bornhald. He would never have fallen to the Seanchan!"

"ðæts fulɪʃnəs," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ðə sintʃæn əv biɾən əs oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əɡɛn. ivən ə ɡʊd mæn kən fɔl ɪn bæɾəl."

"That's foolishness," Galad said. "The Seanchan have beaten us over and over again. Even a good man can fall in battle."

"aɪ sɔ ɡoʊldeɪniz ðɛɹ," baɪɑɝ sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn. "faɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd ɡoʊsli æpɹɪʃənz! kɹitʃɝz ʌv ivəl!"

"I saw Goldeneyes there," Byar said, gesturing toward Perrin. "Fighting alongside ghostly apparitions! Creatures of evil!"

"ðə hɪɹoʊz ə ðə hɔɹn, baɪɑɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "kʊdn jə si ðət wi wɛɹ faɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə waɪtkloʊks?"

"The Heroes of the Horn, Byar," Perrin said. "Couldn't you see that we where fighting alongside the Whitecloaks?"

"ju sim tə bi," baɪɑɝ sɛd waɪldli. "dʒʌst əz jə sim tə bi dɪfɛndɪŋ ðə pipəl ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. bʌɾ aɪ sɔ θɹu ju, ʃæɾoʊzpɔn! aɪ sɔ θɹu jə ðə moʊmən aɪ mɛt ju!"

"You seemed to be," Byar said wildly. "Just as you seemed to be defending the people in the Two Rivers. But I saw through you, Shadowspawn! I saw through you the moment I met you!"

"ɪz ðət waɪ jə toʊl mi tə ɪskeɪp?" pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "wɛn aɪ wɑz kənfaɪn ɪn ði ɛldɝ lɔɹd bɔɹnhəlz tɛnt, fɑloʊɪŋ maɪ kæptʃɝ. jə ɡeɪv mi ə ʃɑɹp ɹɑk tə kʌt maɪ bɑnz ən toʊl mi ðəɾ ɪf aɪ ɹæn, noʊbɑdi wəd tʃeɪs mi."

"Is that why you told me to escape?" Perrin said softly. "When I was confined in the elder Lord Bornhald's tent, following my capture. You gave me a sharp rock to cut my bonds and told me that if I ran, nobody would chase me."

baɪɑɝ fɹoʊz. hi sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən ðəɾ əntɪl ðɪs moʊmənt.

Byar froze. He seemed to have forgotten that until this moment.

"ju wɑntəd mi tə tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "soʊ ðət jə kəd kɪl mi. jə wɑntəɾ ɛɡwin ən mi dɛd vɛɹi bædli."

"You wanted me to try to get away," Perrin said, "so that you could kill me. You wanted Egwene and me dead very badly."

"ɪz ðɪs tʃɹu, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

"Is this true, Child Byar?" Galad asked.

baɪɑɝ stʌmbəld. "ʌv kɔɹs ... ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. aɪ. . . ." sʌɾənli, hi spʌn ən tɝn tə mɔɹɡeɪs ətɑp əɹ sɪmpəl θɹoʊn ə dʒʌdʒmənt. "ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl ɪz nɑɾ əbaʊt mi, bʌt hɪm! juv hɝd boʊθ saɪdz. wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ ænsɝ? dʒʌdʒ, wʊmən!"

Byar stumbled. "Of course ... of course not. I. . . ." Suddenly, he spun and turned to Morgase atop her simple throne of judgment. "This trial is not about me, but him! You have heard both sides. What is your answer? Judge, woman!"

"ju ʃəd nɑt spik tə maɪ mʌðɝ soʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd kwaɪətli. hɪz feɪs wɑz ɪmpæsɪv, bʌt pɛɹɪn smɛl deɪnʒɝ ɑn hɪm. bɔɹnhəld, lʊkɪŋ vɛɹi tʃɹʌbəld, hæd sæt bæk daʊn ən wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɪz hɛd wɪð ɪz hænd.

"You should not speak to my mother so," Galad said quietly. His face was impassive, but Perrin smelled danger on him. Bornhald, looking very troubled, had sat back down and was holding his head with his hand.

"noʊ, ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "hi ɪz ɹaɪt. ðɪs tʃɹaɪəl ɪz əbaʊt pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." ʃi tɝn fɹəm baɪɑɝ tə ɹəɡɑɹd pɛɹɪn. hi lʊk bæk kɑmli. ʃi smɛld ... əz ɪf ʃi wɝ kjʊɹiəs əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. "lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə. dʒju fil juv spoʊkən æɾəkwətli fəɹ jɝsɛlf?"

"No, it is all right," Morgase said. "He is right. This trial is about Perrin Aybara." She turned from Byar to regard Perrin. He looked back calmly. She smelled ... as if she were curious about something. "Lord Aybara. Do you feel you have spoken adequately for yourself?"

"aɪ wɑz pɹətɛktɪŋ maɪsɛlf ən maɪ fɹɛnz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə waɪt-kloʊks hæd noʊ əθɔɹəɾi tə də əz ðeɪ dɪd, ɔɹɾɝɪŋ əs aʊt, θɹɛɾənɪŋ ʌs. jə noʊ ðɛɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən əz wɛl əz ɛni, aɪ səspɛkt. wi hæd ɡʊd ɹizən tə bi wɛɹi ʌv əm ən dɪsəbeɪ ðɛɹ ɔɹɾɝz. ɪt wɑzn mɝɾɝ. aɪ wɑz dʒʌs dɪfɛndɪŋ maɪsɛlf."

"I was protecting myself and my friends," Perrin said. "The White-cloaks had no authority to do as they did, ordering us out, threatening us. You know their reputation as well as any, I suspect. We had good reason to be wary of them and disobey their orders. It wasn't murder. I was just defending myself."

mɔɹɡeɪs nɑɾəd. "aɪ wɪl meɪk maɪ dɪsɪʒən, ðɛn."

Morgase nodded. "I will make my decision, then."

"wʌɾ ə hævɪŋ ʌðɝz spik fəɹ pɛɹɪn?" feɪl dɪmændəd, stændɪŋ.

"What of having others speak for Perrin?" Faile demanded, standing.
