Egwene swore she could almost feel the woman watching her in Tel'aran'rhiod. Yukiri and her group were at a standstill.

hɝ bɛs hoʊp wɑz ðə miɾɪŋ tənaɪt. ɪt hæd tə dʒɹɔ hɝ. ɛɡwin dɪdn əv ɛni taɪm lɛft - ðə mɑnɑɹks ʃid pɝsweɪɾəd wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə muv, ən ɹændz fɔɹsɪz wɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ.

Her best hope was the meeting tonight. It had to draw her. Egwene didn't have any time left - the monarchs she'd persuaded were already beginning to move, and Rand's forces were gathering.

tənaɪt. ɪt mʌs hæpən tənaɪt.

Tonight. It must happen tonight.

"ɡoʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "spik wɪð ði ʌðɝz. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðəɹ tə bi ɛni fulɪʃ mɪsteɪks."

"Go," Egwene said. "Speak with the others. I don't want there to be any foolish mistakes."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," sɪuən ɡɹʌmbəld, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ.

"Yes, Mother," Siuan grumbled, turning away.

ən sɪuən," ɛɡwin kɔld æftɝ hɝ.

And Siuan," Egwene called after her.

ðə fɔɹmɝ æmɪɝlɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "si tə jəɹ seɪfti tənaɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ wəd nɑt luz ju."

The former Amyrlin hesitated. "See to your safety tonight," Egwene said. "I would not lose you."

sɪuən ɔfən ɡeɪv sətʃ kənsɝn ə kɹʌsti ɹɪplaɪ, bʌt tənaɪt ʃi smaɪld ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən hɝiɾ ɑn tə hɝ ɹumz, wɛɹ ʃi faʊn sɪl-viænə weɪɾɪŋ.

Siuan often gave such concern a crusty reply, but tonight she smiled Egwene shook her head and hurried on to her rooms, where she found Sil-viana waiting.

"ɡɔɪn?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Gawyn?" Egwene asked.

"ðɛɹ əz bɪn noʊ nuz ə hɪm," sɪlviænə ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ fəɹ ɪm ðɪs æftɝnun, bʌt ðə mɛsənʒɝ hæzən ɹɪtɝnd. aɪ səspɛk ðət ɡɔɪn ɪz dɪleɪɪŋ ɪz ɹɪplaɪ tə bi dɪfəkəlt."

"There has been no news of him," Silviana replied. "I sent a messenger for him this afternoon, but the messenger hasn't returned. I suspect that Gawyn is delaying his reply to be difficult."

"hiz nʌθɪŋ ɪf nɑt stʌbɝn," ɛɡwin sɛd. ʃi fɛlt ɪkspoʊzd wɪθaʊt hɪm. ðət wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ, sɪns ʃid pɔɪntɪdli ɔɹɾɝd ɪm tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ dɔɹ. naʊ ʃi wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɪm nɑt biɪŋ ðɛɹ?

"He's nothing if not stubborn," Egwene said. She felt exposed without him. That was surprising, since she'd pointedly ordered him to stay away from her door. Now she worried about him not being there?

"dʌbəl maɪ ɡɑɹd, ən meɪk sɝɾən tə hæv soʊlʒɝz poʊstɪd nɪɹbaɪ ɪf maɪ wɔɹdz ɡoʊ ɔf, ðəl ɹeɪz ə klæɾɝ."

"Double my guard, and make certain to have soldiers posted nearby If my wards go off, they will raise a clatter."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd.

"Yes, Mother," Silviana said.

"æn sɛnd ɡɔɪn ənʌðɝ mɛsənʒɝ," ʃi sɛd. "wʌn wɪð ə mɔɹ pəlaɪtli wɝɾɪd lɛɾɝ. æsk ɪm tə ɹɪtɝn; doʊn ɔɹɾɝ hɪm." noʊɪŋ sɪlviænəz əpɪnjən ʌv ɡɔɪn, ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ði ɝɪdʒənəl lɛɾɝ hæd bɪn bɹʌsk.

"And send Gawyn another messenger," she said. "One with a more politely worded letter. Ask him to return; don't order him." Knowing Silviana's opinion of Gawyn, Egwene was sure the original letter had been brusque.

wɪð ðæt, ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən wɛn ɪndə hɝ ɹumz, tʃɛkt ɑn əɹ wɔɹdz, ən pɹipɛɹd tə ɡoʊ tə slip.

With that, Egwene took a deep breath, then went into her rooms, checked on her wards, and prepared to go to sleep.

sɛvən ʃʊdn fil soʊ ɪɡzɔstəd, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əz i klaɪm daʊn fɹəm stɛpɝ. aɪ dɪdn də ɛniθɪŋ bʌt tɔk.

7 shouldn't feel so exhausted, Perrin thought as he climbed down from Stepper. I didn't do anything but talk.

ðə tʃɹaɪəl weɪɾ ɑn hɪm. ɪt sim tə weɪ əpɑn ði ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi. pɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ əm əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd bæk ɪndə kæmp. mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz ðɛɹ, ɔf ɑn əɹ oʊn. feɪl hæd wɑtʃt əɹ ðə hoʊl weɪ bæk, smɛlɪŋ ʌv æŋɡɝ, bʌt nɑt spikɪŋ ə wɝd. æliændɝ ən bɹəleɪn hæd kɛp ðɛɹ dɪstəns.

The trial weighed on him. It seemed to weigh upon the entire army. Perrin looked at them as they rode back into camp. Morgase was there, off on her own. Faile had watched her the whole way back, smelling of anger, but not speaking a word. Alliandre and Berelain had kept their distance.

mɔɹɡeɪs hæd kəndɛm hɪm, bʌɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi dɪdn mʌtʃ kɛɹ. hi hæd dɪflɛktɪd ðə waɪtkloʊks;

Morgase had condemned him, but in truth, he didn't much care. He had deflected the Whitecloaks;

naʊ hi niɾəd tə liɾ ɪz pipəl tə seɪfti. mɔɹɡeɪs ɹoʊd θɹu kæmp, sikɪŋ aʊt lini ən mæstɝ ɡɪl. ðeɪɾ ɝaɪv seɪfli, təɡɛðɝ wɪð ɔl ði ʌðɝ kæptɪvz, əz ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd hæd pɹɑməst.

now he needed to lead his people to safety. Morgase rode through camp, seeking out Lini and Master Gill. They'd arrived safely, together with all the other captives, as Galad Damodred had promised.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, hid sɛn ðə səplaɪz ən kɑɹts wɪð ðɛm.

Surprisingly, he'd sent the supplies and carts with them.

ðə tʃɹaɪəl wɑz ə vɪktɝi, ðɛn. pɛɹɪnz mɛn dɪdn sim tə si ɪt ðət weɪ. ðə soʊlʒɝz splɪɾ ɪndə ɡɹups əz ðeɪ slʌŋk bæk ɪndə kæmp. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl tɔkɪŋ.

The trial was a victory, then. Perrin's men didn't seem to see it that way. The soldiers split into groups as they slunk back into camp. There was little talking.

bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn, ɡɔl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "tu sɪlvɝ pɔɪns."

Beside Perrin, Gaul shook his head. "Two silver points."

"wʌts ðæt?" pɛɹɪn æskt, hændɪŋ stɛpɝ tə ə ɡɹum.

"What's that?" Perrin asked, handing Stepper to a groom.

"ə seɪɪŋ," ɡɔl sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp ət ðə skaɪ. "tu sɪlvɝ pɔɪns. twaɪs wɪv ɹɪɾən tə bæɾəl ən faʊnd noʊ foʊ. wʌns mɔɹ, ən wi luz ɑnɝ.

"A saying," Gaul said, glancing up at the sky. "Two silver points. Twice we have ridden to battle and found no foe. Once more, and we lose honor.

"bɛɾɝ tə faɪnd noʊ foʊ, ɡɔl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bɛɾɝ noʊ blʌd bi ʃɛd.'

"Better to find no foe, Gaul," Perrin said. "Better no blood be shed.'

ɡɔl læft. "aɪ də nɑt seɪ aɪ wɪʃ tə ɛn ðə dʒɹim, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. bʌt lʊk ət jəɹ mɛn. ðeɪ kən fil wʌɾ aɪ seɪ. jə ʃəd nɑt dæns ðə spɪɹz wɪθaʊt pɝpəs, bʌt niðɝ ʃəd jə tu ɔfən dɪmæn ðət mɛn pɹipɛɹ ðɛmsɛlvz tə kɪl, ðən ɡɪv əm noʊbɑdi tə faɪt." "aɪl də ɪɾ əz ɔfən əz aɪ laɪk," pɛɹɪn sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ, "ɪf ɪt minz əvɔɪɾɪŋ ə bæɾəl. aɪ - "

Gaul laughed. "I do not say I wish to end the dream, Perrin Aybara. But look at your men. They can feel what I say. You should not dance the spears without purpose, but neither should you too often demand that men prepare themselves to kill, then give them nobody to fight." "I'll do it as often as I like," Perrin said gruffly, "if it means avoiding a battle. I - "

ə hɔɹsəz hʊvz θʌmp ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ðə wɪn bɹɔɾ ɪm feɪlz sɛn əz i tɝn tə feɪs hɝ.

A horse's hooves thumped the ground, and the wind brought him Faile's scent as he turned to face her.

"ə bæɾəl əvɔɪɾəd ɪndid, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɡɔl sɛd, "æn ənʌðɝ ɪnvaɪɾəd. meɪ jə faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd." hi tʃɹɑɾəd əweɪ əz feɪl dɪsmaʊntɪd.

"A battle avoided indeed, Perrin Aybara," Gaul said, "and another invited. May you find water and shade." He trotted away as Faile dismounted.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ.

Perrin took a deep breath.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, hʌzbənd," ʃi sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm. "ju wɪl ɪkspleɪn tə mi dʒʌst wʌt jə θɔt jə wɝ duɪŋ. jə lɛɾ ɪm pæs dʒʌdʒmən ɑn ju? jə pɹɑməs tə dɪlɪvɝ jɝsɛlf tə hɪm? aɪ wɑzn ʌndɝ ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðəɾ aɪd mɛɹiɾ ə ful!"

"All right, husband," she said, striding up to him. "You will explain to me just what you thought you were doing. You let him pass judgment on you? You promised to deliver yourself to him? I wasn't under the impression that I'd married a fool!"

"ɪm noʊ ful, wʊmən," hi ɹɔɹd bæk. "ju kip tɛlɪŋ mi aɪ nid tə lid. wɛl, tədeɪ aɪ tʊk jəɹ ædvaɪs!"

"I'm no fool, woman," he roared back. "You keep telling me I need to lead. Well, today I took your advice!"

"ju tʊk ɪɾ ən meɪd ðə ɹɔŋ dɪsɪʒən."

"You took it and made the wrong decision."

"ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən!"

"There was no right decision!"

"ju cʊɾə lɛɾ əs faɪt ðɛm."

"You could have let us fight them."

"ðeɪ ɪntɛn tə faɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɛvɹi waɪt-kloʊk wi kɪld wəd bi wʌn lɛs mæn tə feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn. meɪn, maɪ mɛn, ðə waɪtkloʊks - nʌn ʌv əs mæɾɝ kəmpɛɹd tə wʌɾ ɪz kʌmɪŋ! ðeɪ hæd tə lɪv, ən soʊ dɪd wi. ən ðɪs wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ!"

"They intend to fight at the Last Battle," Perrin said. "Every White-cloak we killed would be one less man to face the Dark One. Me, my men, the Whitecloaks - none of us matter compared to what is coming! They had to live, and so did we. And this was the only way!"

laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɹɔŋ tə jɛl ət hɝ. jɛɾ ɪɾ æktʃəli  sɔfən əɹ tɛmpɝ. ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, ðə soʊlʒɝz nɪɹbaɪ hɪm stɑɹɾəd tə nɑd, əz ɪf ðeɪ hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə si ðə tʃɹuθ əntɪl hid bɛloʊɾ ɪɾ aʊt.

Light, but it felt wrong to yell at her. Yet it actually softened her temper. Remarkably, the soldiers nearby him started to nod, as if they hadn't been able to see the truth until he'd bellowed it out.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə teɪk kəmæn ə ðə ɹitʃɹit," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə feɪl. "ðə tʃɹæp hæzən spɹʌŋ jɛt, bʌɾ aɪ faɪn maɪsɛlf ɪtʃɪŋ mɔɹ itʃ mɪnət. sʌmθɪŋz wɑtʃɪŋ ʌs; ðeɪv teɪkən əweɪ əɹ ɡeɪtweɪz, ən ðeɪ ɪntɛn tə si əs dɛd. ðeɪ naʊ noʊ wi woʊn faɪt ðə waɪtkloʊks, wɪtʃ minz ðəl ətæk sun. meɪbi ðɪs ivnɪŋ; ɪf wɝ lʌki, ðəl dɪleɪ əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ."

"I want you to take command of the retreat," Perrin said to Faile. "The trap hasn't sprung yet, but I find myself itching more each minute. Something's watching us; they have taken away our gateways, and they intend to see us dead. They now know we won't fight the Whitecloaks, which means they'll attack soon. Maybe this evening; if we're lucky, they'll delay until tomorrow morning."

wi ɑɹən dʌn wɪð ðɪs ɑɹɡjəmənt," ʃi wɔɹnd.

We aren't done with this argument," she warned.

wʌts dʌn ɪz dʌn, feɪl. lʊk fɔɹwɝd."

What's done is done, Faile. Look forward."

vɛɹi wɛl." ʃi stɪl smɛld æŋɡɹi, ðoʊz bjuɾəfəl dɑɹk aɪz ə hɝz fɪɹs, bʌt ʃi kənteɪn ɪt.

Very well." She still smelled angry, those beautiful dark eyes of hers fierce, but she contained it.

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd ði ɛdʒ ə kæmp, wɛɹ ðɛɹ tɛn leɪ.

"I'm going to the wolf dream," Perrin said, glancing toward the edge of camp, where their tent lay.

"ɪl iðɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðət doʊm, əɹ əl faɪn ə weɪ tə fɔɹs sleɪɝ tə tɛl mi haʊ tə meɪk tʃɹævlɪŋ wɝk əɡɛn. ɡɛt ðə pipəl ɹɛɾi tə mɑɹtʃ, ən əv ði æʃəmən tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɑn ɛvɹi kaʊn ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd. ðə moʊmən ɪt wɝks, ɡɛɾ əɹ pipəl aʊɾ ə hɪɹ."

"Ill either destroy that dome, or I'll find a way to force Slayer to tell me how to make Traveling work again. Get the people ready to march, and have the Asha'man try to make a gateway on every count of a hundred. The moment it works, get our people out of here."

"wɛɹ?" feɪl æskt. "dʒəhænə?"

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "tu kloʊz. ði ɛnəmi maɪt bi wɑtʃɪŋ θɝ ændɝ. teɪk əm tə keɪɛmlɪn. æktʃəli , noʊ. waɪtbɹɪdʒ. lɛts steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ðeɪ maɪɾ ɪkspɛkt. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ wɑnə tə ʃoʊ ʌp wɪð ən ɑɹmi ɑn ɪleɪnz dɔɹstɛp əntɪl aɪv wɔɹn hɝ."

Perrin shook his head. "Too close. The enemy might be watching ther Andor. Take them to Caemlyn. Actually, no. Whitebridge. Let's stay away from anywhere they might expect. Besides, I don't want to show up with an army on Elayne's doorstep until I've warned her."

"ə ɡʊd plæn," feɪl sɛd. "ɪf jə fɪɹ ətæk, wi ʃəd muv ðə kɑɹnp fɑloʊɝz fɝst, ɹæðɝ ðən muvɪŋ ði ɑɹmiz θɹu ən livɪŋ əs ʌndɪfɛndəd."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "bʌt ɡɛɾ əm muvɪŋ əz sun əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪz wɝk əɡɛn."

Perrin nodded. "But get them moving as soon as the gateways work again."

"æn ɪf jə doʊn səksid?" feɪl hæd bɪɡʌn tə saʊn dɪtɝmənd. fɹaɪɾənd, bʌt dɪtɝmənd.

"ɪf aɪ hævən ɹɪstɔɹd ɡeɪtweɪz ɪn wʌn aʊɝ, stɑɹɾ əm mɑɹtʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə pɝɪməɾɝ wɛɹ nil dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ i kən meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðət wɪl wɝk; aɪ θɪŋk sleɪɝ wɪl dʒʌs muv ðə doʊm, ɔlweɪz kipɪŋ əs ʌndɝniθ ɪt. bʌɾ ɪts sʌmθɪŋ."

"If I haven't restored gateways in one hour, start them marching toward the perimeter where Neald discovered that he can make gateways. I don't think that will work; I think Slayer will just move the dome, always keeping us underneath it. But it's something."

feɪl nɑɾəd, bʌɾ əɹ sɛn bɪkeɪm hɛzɪɾənt. "ðæt wɪl ɔlsoʊ pʊɾ əs mɑɹtʃɪŋ, ɹæðɝ ðən ɪn kæmp.

Faile nodded, but her scent became hesitant. "That will also put us marching, rather than in camp.

mʌtʃ iziɝ tə æmbʊʃ ðət weɪ."

Much easier to ambush that way."

"aɪ noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz waɪ aɪ mʌs nɑt feɪl."

"I know," Perrin said. "That is why I must not fail."

ʃi tʊk ɪm ɪndə hɝ ɑɹmz, hɛɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. ʃi smɛl soʊ wʌndɝfəl. laɪk feɪl. ðət wɑz ðə dɛfənɪʃən ʌv wʌndɝfəl tə hɪm. "juv sɛd hiz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən jə ɑɹ," ʃi wɪspɝd.

She took him into her arms, head against his chest. She smelled so wonderful. Like Faile. That was the definition of wonderful to him. "You've said he's stronger than you are," she whispered.

"hi ɪz."

"He is."

"kæn aɪ də ɛniθɪŋ tə hɛlp jə feɪs hɪm?" ʃi æsk sɔfli.

"Can I do anything to help you face him?" she asked softly.

"ɪf jə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ əm waɪl aɪm ɡɔn, ðət wɪl hɛlp."

"If you watch over them while I'm gone, that will help."

"wʌt hæpənz ɪf i kɪlz jə waɪl jəɹ ðɛɹ?"

"What happens if he kills you while you're there?"

pɛɹɪn dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ.

Perrin didn't reply.

"ðɛɹz noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ?" ʃi æskt.

"There's no other way?" she asked.

hi pʊl bæk fɹəm hɝ. "feɪl, aɪm fɛɹli sɝɾən ðət hiz lɔɹd luk. ðeɪ smɛl dɪfɹənt, bʌt ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ sɪməlɝ əbaʊt ðɛm, tu. ən wən aɪ wundəd sleɪɝ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim bɪfɔɹ, luk bɔɹ ðə waʊnd."

He pulled back from her. "Faile, I'm fairly certain that he's Lord Luc. They smell different, but there's something similar about them, too. And when I wounded Slayer in the wolf dream before, Luc bore the wound."

"ɪz ðət səpoʊz tə hɛlp mi fil bɛɾɝ?" ʃi æskt, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ.

"Is that supposed to help me feel better?" she asked, grimacing.

"ɪts ɔl kʌmɪŋ bæk ɝaʊnd. wi fɪnɪʃ wɪð meɪɾən ən faɪn aʊɝsɛlvz wɪðɪn ə stoʊnz tɔs ə ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə waɪtkloʊks, baɪɑɝ ən bɔɹnhəld wɪð ðɛm. sleɪɝ əpɪɹz ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim əɡɛn.

"It's all coming back around. We finish with Maiden and find ourselves within a stone's toss of the remnants of the Whitecloaks, Byar and Bornhald with them. Slayer appears in the wolf dream again.

ðət mæn aɪ toʊl jə ʌv, noʊm, ðə wʌn u wɑz ɪn ðə keɪdʒ. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɛɹ aɪ faʊn hɪm?

That man I told you of, Noam, the one who was in the cage. Do you remember where I found him?

"ju sɛd jə wɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ ɹænd. θɹu . . ."

"You said you were chasing Rand. Through . . ."

"ɡildən," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪt hæpənd nɑt wʌn wiks ɹaɪd fɹəm hɪɹ."

"Ghealdan," Perrin said. "It happened not one week's ride from here."

"æn ɑd koʊɪnsɪɾəns, bʌt - "

"An odd coincidence, but - "

"noʊ koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz, feɪl. nɑt wɪð mi. aɪm hɪɹ fəɹ ə ɹizən. hiz hɪɹ fəɹ ə ɹizən. aɪ mʌs feɪs ðɪs."

"No coincidences, Faile. Not with me. I'm here for a reason. He's here for a reason. I must face this."

ʃi nɑɾəd. hi tɝn tə wɔk təwɔɹd ðɛɹ tɛnt, hɝ hæn slɪpɪŋ fɹi ʌv hɪz. ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə ti ðət wəd lɛɾ ɪm slip soʊ hi kəɾ ɛntɝ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

She nodded. He turned to walk toward their tent, her hand slipping free of his. The Wise Ones had given him a tea that would let him sleep so he could enter the wolf dream.

ɪt wɑz taɪm.

It was time.

"haʊ kəd jə lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ?" baɪɑɝ sɛd, nʌkəlz klɛntʃt ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd, waɪt kloʊk flæpɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi, bɔɹnhəld ən ɡɑləd wɔk θɹu ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛɹ kæmp.

"How could you let him go?" Byar said, knuckles clenched on the pommel of his sword, white cloak flapping behind him. He, Bornhald and Galad walked through the middle of their camp.

"aɪ dɪd wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"I did what was right," Galad said.

"lɛɾɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ fɹi wɑz nɑt ɹaɪt!" baɪɑɝ sɛd. "ju kæn bɪliv - "

"Letting him go free was not right!" Byar said. "You can't believe - "

"tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ," ɡɑləd sɛd sɔfli, "aɪ faɪn jəɹ æɾətud ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɪnsəbɔɹɾəneɪt. ðət tʃɹʌbəlz mi.

"Child Byar," Galad said softly, "I find your attitude increasingly insubordinate. That troubles me.

ɪt ʃəd tʃɹʌbəl jə əz wɛl."

It should trouble you as well."

baɪɑɝ kloʊzd ɪz maʊθ ən sɛd noʊ mɔɹ, ðoʊ ɡɑləd kəd si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl fəɹ ɪm tə hoʊld ɪz tʌŋ. bɪhaɪn baɪɑɝ, bɔɹnhəld wɔk saɪlənli, lʊkɪŋ vɛɹi əpsɛt.

Byar closed his mouth and said no more, though Galad could see that it was difficult for him to hold his tongue. Behind Byar, Bornhald walked silently, looking very upset.

"aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə wɪl kip ɪz oʊθ," ɡɑləd sɛd. "æn ɪf i dʌz nɑt, aɪ naʊ hæv ðə liɡəl ɡɹaʊnz tə hʌn ɪm ən ɪɡzæk pʌnɪʃmənt. ɪts nɑɾ aɪdil, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz wɪzdəm tə hɪz wɝdz. aɪ də bɪliv ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ən ɪf soʊ, ɪts taɪm tə junaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ."

"I believe that Aybara will keep his oath," Galad said. "And if he does not, I now have the legal grounds to hunt him and exact punishment. It is not ideal, but there was wisdom to his words. I do believe the Last Battle is coming, and if so, it is time to unite against the Shadow."

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," baɪɑɝ sɛd, mænɪdʒɪŋ ɪz toʊn, "wɪð ɔl ɹɪspɛkt, ðət mæn ɪz ə ðə ʃædoʊ. hɪl nɑt bi faɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ʌs, bʌɾ əɡɛnst ʌs."

"My Lord Captain Commander," Byar said, managing his tone, "with all respect, that man is of the Shadow. He will not be fighting beside us, but against us."

"ɪf ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu," ɡɑləd sɛd, "wi wɪl stɪl əv ə tʃæns tə feɪs ɪm ɑn ðə fild ə bæɾəl. aɪ hæv meɪd maɪ dɪsɪʒən, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ." hɑɹnɪʃ stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə dʒɔɪn əm ən səluɾəd. ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. "tʃaɪl hɑɹnɪʃ, stʃɹaɪk kæmp."

"If that is true," Galad said, "we will still have a chance to face him on the field of battle. I have made my decision, Child Byar." Harnesh strode up to join them and saluted. Galad nodded. "Child Harnesh, strike camp."

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ? ðɪs leɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ?"

"My Lord Captain Commander? This late in the day?"

'jɛs," ɡɑləd sɛd. "wi wɪl mɑɹtʃ ɪndə ðə naɪɾ ən pʊt səm dɪstəns bɪtwin əs ən eɪbɑɹə, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. liv skaʊts, meɪk sɝɾən i dʌzn tʃɹaɪ tə fɑloʊ ʌs. wɪl meɪk fəɹ luɡɹd. wi kən ɹəkɹuɾ ən ɹisəp-plaɪ, ðən kəntɪnju ɑn təwɔɹɾ ændɝ."

'Yes," Galad said. "We will march into the night and put some distance between us and Aybara, just in case. Leave scouts, make certain he doesn't try to follow us. We'll make for Lugard. We can recruit and resup-ply, then continue on toward Andor."

jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," hɑɹnɪʃ sɛd.

Yes, my Lord Captain Commander," Harnesh said.

ɡɑləd tɝn tə baɪɑɝ əz hɑɹnɪʃ lɛft. ðə skɛləɾəl mæn ɡeɪv ə səlut, sʌŋkən aɪz deɪnʒɝəsli ɹɪzɛnfəl, ðən stɔkt ɔf. ɡɑləd stɑpt ɑn ðə fild, bɪtwin waɪt tɛns, hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əz i wɑtʃt mɛsənʒɝz ɹileɪ hɪz ɔɹɾɝz θɹu kæmp.

Galad turned to Byar as Harnesh left. The skeletal man gave a salute, sunken eyes dangerously resentful, then stalked off. Galad stopped on the field, between white tents, hands behind his back as he watched messengers relay his orders through camp.

"ju ɑɹ kwaɪət, tʃaɪl bɔɹnhəld," ɡɑləd sɛɾ æftɝ ə fju moʊməns. eɪt jə əz dɪsplizd wɪð maɪ ækʃənz əz tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ ɪz?"

"You are quiet, Child Bornhald," Galad said after a few moments. Ate you as displeased with my actions as Child Byar is?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," bɔɹnhəl sɛd. "aɪv bɪliv fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə kɪl maɪ fɑðɝ. ən jɛt, siɪŋ haʊ jɹəɾ æks, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɪz dɪskɹɪpʃən... ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɛvəɾəns. ɪt fɹʌstʃɹeɪts mi tə ədmɪɾ ɪt, ɡɑləd, bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ pɹuf i dɪd kɪl læðən ən jæmwɪk, haʊɛvɝ. hi kɪl tʃɪlʒɹən, soʊ hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"I don't know," Bornhald said. "I've believed for so long that Aybara killed my father. And yet, seeing how Jaret acts, remembering his description... There is no evidence. It frustrates me to admit it, Galad, but I have no proof He did kill Lathin and Yamwick, however. He killed Children, so he is a Darkfriend."

"aɪ kɪld wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, tu," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ænd wɑz neɪm dɑɹk-fɹɛn fəɹ ɪt."

"I killed one of the Children, too," Galad said. "And was named Dark-friend for it."

"ðæt wɑz dɪfɹənt." sʌmθɪŋ sim tə bi tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ bɔɹnhəld, sʌmθɪŋ i wɑzn seɪɪŋ.

"That was different." Something seemed to be troubling Bornhald, something he wasn't saying.

"wɛl, ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu," ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ də nɑt dɪsəɡɹi ðəɾ eɪbɑɹə ʃəd bi pʌnɪʃt, bʌt ðə deɪz ɪvɛns liv mi stʃɹeɪnʒli tʃɹʌbəld."

"Well, that is true," Galad said. "I do not disagree that Aybara should be punished, but the day's events leave me strangely troubled."

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. faɪndɪŋ ænsɝz ʃəd bi izi. ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ ɔlweɪz keɪm tə hɪm.

He shook his head. Finding answers should be easy. The right thing always came to him.

haʊɛvɝ, wɛnɛvɝ i θɔt hid sizd əpɑn ðə ɹaɪt kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ eɪbɑɹə, hi faʊn dɪsteɪsfəl wɝiz kɹɑpɪŋ ʌp ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm.

However, whenever he thought he'd seized upon the right course of action regarding Aybara, he found distasteful worries cropping up inside of him.

laɪf ɪz nɑt soʊ izi əz ðə tɔs ʌv ə kɔɪn, hɪz mʌðɝ hæd sɛd. wʌn saɪɾ əɹ ði ʌðɝ. . . jəɹ sɪmpəl ɪluʒənz . . .

Life is not so easy as the toss of a coin, his mother had said. One side or the other. . . your simple illusions . . .

hi dɪd nɑt laɪk ðə filɪŋ. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl.

He did not like the feeling. Not at all.

pɛɹɪn ɪnheɪl dipli. flaʊɝz blumd ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, ivən əz ðə skaɪ ɹeɪdʒ sɪlvɝ, blæk ən ɡoʊld. ðə sɛns wɝ soʊ ɪŋkɔŋɹuəs. beɪkɪŋ tʃɛɹi paɪ. hɔɹs dʌŋ. ɔɪl ən ɡɹis. soʊp. ə wʊd faɪɝ. ɹəθ. θaɪm. kætfɝn. ə hʌnʒɹəd ʌðɝ ɝbz i kʊdnt neɪm.

Perrin inhaled deeply. Flowers bloomed in the wolf dream, even as the sky raged silver, black and gold. The scents were so incongruous. Baking cherry pie. Horse dung. Oil and grease. Soap. A wood fire. Arrath. Thyme. Catfern. A hundred other herbs he couldn't name.

vɛɹi fju ʌv əm fɪt ðə mɛdoʊ wɛɹ i hæɾ əpɪɹd. hid meɪd sɝɾən nɑt tə əpɪɹ wɛɹ ɪz kæmp wɑz ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim; ðət wʊɾə pʊɾ ɪm tu nɪɹ sleɪɝ.

Very few of them fit the meadow where he had appeared. He'd made certain not to appear where his camp was in the wolf dream; that would have put him too near Slayer.

ðə sɛns wɝ fliɾɪŋ. vænɪʃɪŋ tu kwɪkli, əz ɪf ðeɪd nɛvɝ ɹɪli bɪn ðɛɹ.

The scents were fleeting. Vanishing too quickly, as if they'd never really been there.

hɑpɝ, hi sɛnt.

Hopper, he sent.

/ æm hɪɹ, jʌŋ bʊl. ðə wʊlf əpɪɹd bɪsaɪd hɪm.

/ am here, Young Bull. The wolf appeared beside him.

"ɪt smɛlz stʃɹeɪnʒ."

"It smells strange."

sɛns blɛnd, hɑpɝ sɛnt. laɪk ðə wɔɾɝz ʌv ə θaʊzən stʃɹimz. ɪts nɑt nætʃɹəl. ɪts nɑt ɡʊd.

Scents blend, Hopper sent. Like the waters of a thousand streams. It is not natural. It is not good.

ðɪs pleɪs bɪɡɪnz tə bɹeɪk.

This place begins to break.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. hi ʃɪftəd, əpɪɹɪŋ ni dip ɪn bɹaʊn kɑkəlbɝz dʒʌst aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə vaɪəlɪt doʊm. hɑpɝ əpɪɹd tə hɪz ɹaɪt, widz kɹæklɪŋ əz i muvd əmʌŋ ðɛm.

Perrin nodded. He shifted, appearing knee deep in brown cockleburrs just outside of the violet dome. Hopper appeared to his right, weeds crackling as he moved among them.

ðə doʊm ɹoʊz, ɑmənəs ən ənnætʃɹəl. ə wɪn blu, ʃʌflɪŋ ðə widz ən ʃeɪkɪŋ tʃɹi lɪmz.

The dome rose, ominous and unnatural. A wind blew, shuffling the weeds and shaking tree limbs.

laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt saɪlənli ɪn ðə skaɪ.

Lightning flashed silently in the sky.

hiz ðɛɹ, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ɔlweɪz.

He is there, Hopper sent. Always.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. dɪd sleɪɝ kʌm tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ðə weɪ pɛɹɪn dɪd? ən dɪd spɛndɪŋ taɪm ɪn ɪt liv ɪm stɪl taɪɝd, əz ɪt dɪd pɛɹɪn? ðə mæn nɛvɝ sim tə liv ðɪs ɛɹiə.

Perrin nodded. Did Slayer come to the wolf dream the way Perrin did? And did spending time in it leave him still tired, as it did Perrin? The man never seemed to leave this area.

hi wɑz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim tə dɪseɪbəl ðə doʊm.

He was guarding something. There had to be a way in the wolf dream to disable the dome.

jʌŋ bʊl, wi kʌm. ðə sɛndɪŋ wɑz fɹəm oʊk dænsɝ. hɝ pæk wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, naʊ oʊnli θɹi stʃɹɔŋ. spɑɹks, baʊnləs, oʊk dænsɝ hɝsɛlf. ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən tə kʌm hɪɹ, ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɔɪn ðə wʊlvz ɹʌnɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd.

Young Bull, we come. The sending was from Oak Dancer. Her pack was approaching, now only three strong. Sparks, Boundless, Oak Dancer herself. They had chosen to come here, rather than join the wolves running northward.

ðə θɹi əpɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɑpɝ. pɛɹɪn lʊk tə ðɛm, ən sɛn kənsɝn. ðɪs wɪl bi deɪnʒɝəs. wʊlvz meɪ daɪ.

The three appeared behind Hopper. Perrin looked to them, and sent concern. This will be dangerous. Wolves may die.

ðɛɹ sɛndɪŋ bæk wɑz ɪnsɪstənt. sleɪɝ mʌs fɔl fəɹ wʌt hiz dʌn. təɡɛðɝ wəɹ stʃɹɔŋ.

Their sending back was insistent. Slayer must fall for what he has done. Together we are strong.

jʌŋ bʊl ʃəd nɑt hʌn sətʃ deɪnʒɝəs pɹeɪ əloʊn.

Young Bull should not hunt such dangerous prey alone.

hi nɑɾəd ɪn əɡɹimənt, lɛɾɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ əpɪɹ ɪn ɪz hænd. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə doʊm. pɛɹɪn wɔkt ɪndə ɪt wɪð ə sloʊ, dɪtɝmən stʃɹaɪd. hi ɹəfjuz tə fil wiknəs. hi wɑz stʃɹɔŋ. ðə doʊm wɑz nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɛɹ. hi bɪliv ðə wɝl tə bi əz i wɪʃt ɪt.

He nodded in agreement, letting his hammer appear in his hand. Together, they approached the dome. Perrin walked into it with a slow, determined stride. He refused to feel weakness. He was strong. The dome was nothing but air. He believed the world to be as he wished it.

hi stʌmbəld, bʌt pʊl θɹu ɪndə ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə doʊm. ðə lændskeɪp fɛl feɪnli dɑɹkɝ hɪɹ. ɛldɝ tʃɹiz mɔɹ dɪm ə bɑɹk, ðə daɪɪŋ dɔɡfən-nɛl ə dipɝ ɡɹin əɹ bɹaʊn. hɑpɝ ən ðə pæk muv θɹu ðə doʊm ɝaʊn hɪm.

He stumbled, but pulled through into the inside of the dome. The landscape felt faintly darker here. Elder trees more dim of bark, the dying dogfen-nel a deeper green or brown. Hopper and the pack moved through the dome around him.

wi meɪk fəɹ ðə sɛntɝ, pɛɹɪn sɛnt. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə sikɹət tə dɪskʌvɝ, ɪɾəl pɹɑbli bi ðɛɹ.

We make for the center, Perrin sent. If there is a secret to discover, it will probably be there.

ðeɪ muv sloʊli θɹu ðə bɹʌʃ ən stænz ə tʃɹiz. pɛɹɪn ɪmpoʊzd ɪz wɪl əpɑn ði ɛɹiə ɝaʊn hɪm, ən ðə livz stɑp kɹæklɪŋ, widz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ saɪlənt wən i bɹʌʃt əɡɛns ðɛm.

They moved slowly through the brush and stands of trees. Perrin imposed his will upon the area around him, and the leaves stopped crackling, weeds remaining silent when he brushed against them.

ðət wɑz nætʃɹəl. ɪt wɑz ðə weɪ θɪŋz ʃəd bi. soʊ ɪt wɑz.

That was natural. It was the way things should be. So it was.

ɪt wəd bi ə lɔŋ dɪstəns tə ðə sɛntɝ, soʊ pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn hɑpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. nɑt dʒʌmps əɹ stɛps; hi sɪmpli stɑp biɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs, əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ə dɪfɹən loʊkeɪʃən. hi mæskt ɪz sɛnt, ðoʊ sleɪɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊlf.

It would be a long distance to the center, so Perrin began hopping forward. Not jumps or steps; he simply stopped being in one place, appearing in a different location. He masked his scent, though Slayer was not a wolf.

ðəɾ əz tə bɪkʌm maɪ ædvæntɪdʒ, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əz ðeɪ ɡɹu kloʊsɝ ən kloʊsɝ tə ðə sɛntɝ. hiz mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðən aɪ. bʌɾ aɪ hæv ðə wʊlf wɪðɪn mi. ðɪs pleɪs ɪz əɹ dʒɹim. hiz ði ɪnveɪɾɝ.

That has to become my advantage, Perrin thought as they grew closer and closer to the center. He is more experienced than I. But I have the wolf within me. This place is our dream. He is the invader.

haʊɛvɝ skɪld i meɪ bi, hiz nɑt wʌn ʌv ʌs.

However skilled he may be, he is not one of us.

ən ðəɾ ɪz waɪ əl wɪn.

And that is why I will win.

pɛɹɪn smɛl sʌmθɪŋ; ən ɪnkɹisɪŋ ɹɔŋɡnəs ɪn ði ɛɹ. hi ən ðə wʊlvz kɹɛpt ʌp tə ə lɑɹdʒ hɪlsaɪd, ðən pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ə klft ɪn ðə læn ðɛɹ. ə smɔl stæn ʌv ɛldɝ tʃɹiz stʊd dʒʌst əhɛd, pɝhæps fɪfti peɪsɪz əweɪ. lʊkɪŋ ʌp, hi dʒʌdʒ ðɪs tə bi vɛɹi nɪɹ ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə doʊm.

Perrin smelled something; an increasing wrongness in the air. He and the wolves crept up to a large hillside, then peered around a cleft in the land there. A small stand of elder trees stood just ahead, perhaps fifty paces away. Looking up, he judged this to be very near the center of the dome.

juzɪŋ ðə ʃɪftɪŋ weɪ ʌv wʊlvz, ðeɪd tʃɹævəl sɛvɹəl aʊɝz' wɝθ ʌv wɔkɪŋ ɪn ə fju mɪnəts.

Using the shifting way of wolves, they'd traveled several hours' worth of walking in a few minutes.

ðəɾ ɪz ɪt, pɛɹɪn sɛnt. hi lʊkt ət hɑpɝ. ðə wʊlfs sɛnt wɑz mæskt, bʌɾ i wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə noʊ wʊlvz wɛl ɪnʌf tə ɹid kənsɝn ɪn hɑpɝz stɛɹ ən ðə weɪ hi stʊd wɪð fɔɹɛlɛɡz bɛn dʒʌst ə fɹækʃən.

That is it, Perrin sent. He looked at Hopper. The wolf's scent was masked, but he was coming to know wolves well enough to read concern in Hoppers stare and the way he stood with forelegs bent just a fraction.

sʌmθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd.

Something changed.

pɛɹɪn hɝd nʌθɪŋ. hi smɛl nʌθɪŋ. bʌɾ i fɛl sʌmθɪŋ, ə smɔl tʃɹɛmbəl ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Perrin heard nothing. He smelled nothing. But he felt something, a small tremble in the ground.

ɡoʊ! hi sɛnt, vænɪʃɪŋ. hi əpɪɹd tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ tə si ən æɹoʊ hɪt ðə hɪlsaɪd wɛɹ hid bɪn stændɪŋ. ðə ʃæf splɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn, ɪmbɛɾɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɪn ðə ɹɑk ən ɝθ ʌp tə ɪts blæk flɛtʃɪŋ.

Go! he sent, vanishing. He appeared ten paces away to see an arrow hit the hillside where he'd been standing. The shaft split a large stone, embedding itself in the rock and earth up to its black fletching.

sleɪɝ stʊd fɹəm ə kɹaʊtʃ, tɝnɪŋ tə lʊk ət pɛɹɪn əkɹɔs ðə ʃɔɹɾ ɪkspæns ʌv ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz aɪz sim blæk, hɪz skwɛɹ feɪs ʃæɾoʊd, hɪz tɔl bɑɾi mʌskjəlɝ ən deɪnʒɝəs. əz i ɔfən dɪd, hi wɔɹ ə smaɪl. ɹɪli ə snɪɹ. hi wɔɹ lɛðɝ bɹitʃɪz ən ə ʃɝɾ ə dip ɡɹin, fɹɑɹmz ɪkspoʊzd, hæn hoʊldɪŋ ɪz wɪkəd baʊ ʌv dɑɹk wʊd. hi wɔɹ noʊ kwɪvɝ; hi kɹieɪɾəd æɹoʊz əz i niɾəd ðɛm.

Slayer stood from a crouch, turning to look at Perrin across the short expanse of ground. His eyes seemed black, his square face shadowed, his tall body muscular and dangerous. As he often did, he wore a smile. Really a sneer. He wore leather breeches and a shirt of deep green, forearms exposed, hand holding his wicked bow of dark wood. He wore no quiver; he created arrows as he needed them.

pɛɹɪn hɛld ɪz aɪz, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ əz ɪf ɪn tʃælənʒ. ðət wɑz ɪnʌf ʌv ə dɪstʃɹækʃən fəɹ ðə wʊlvz tə ətæk fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

Perrin held his eyes, stepping forward as if in challenge. That was enough of a distraction for the wolves to attack from behind.

sleɪɝ jɛld, spɪnɪŋ əz baʊnləs slæmd ɪndə hɪm. pɛɹɪn wɑz ðəɹ ɪn ən aɪɛblɪŋk, bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ daʊn. sleɪɝ vænɪʃt, ən pɛɹɪn stʃɹʌk oʊnli ɝθ, bʌɾ i kɑɾ ə wɪf ʌv wɛɹ sleɪɝ hæd ɡɔn.

Slayer yelled, spinning as Boundless slammed into him. Perrin was there in an eyeblink, bringing his hammer down. Slayer vanished, and Perrin struck only earth, but he caught a whiff of where Slayer had gone.

hɪɹ? ðət sɛnt wɑz ə ðə seɪm pleɪs ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz. əlɑɹmd, hi lʊkt ʌp tə si sleɪɝ hʌvɝɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ dʒʌst əbʌv, dʒɹɔɪŋ ən æɹoʊ.

Here? That scent was of the same place that Perrin was. Alarmed, he looked up to see Slayer hovering in the air just above, drawing an arrow.

ðə wɪnd, pɛɹɪn θɔt. ɪts soʊ stʃɹɔŋ!

The wind, Perrin thought. It is so strong!

ði æɹoʊ lust, bʌɾ ə sʌɾən ɡʌs blu ɪt saɪdweɪz. ɪt sæŋk ɪndə ði ɝθ dʒʌs bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn. hi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hænz, hɪz oʊn baʊ əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðɛm. ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɔn, æɹoʊ ɪn pleɪs.

The arrow loosed, but a sudden gust blew it sideways. It sank into the earth just beside Perrin. He did not flinch, raising his hands, his own bow appearing in them. Already drawn, arrow in place.

sleɪɝz aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾɝ əz pɛɹɪn lust. sleɪɝ vænɪʃt, əpɪɹɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ - ən hɑpɝ lɛpt ɑn ɪm fɹəm əbʌv, pʊlɪŋ ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. sleɪɝ kɝst wɪð ə ɡʌɾɝəl saʊnd, ðən vænɪʃt.

Slayer's eyes opened wider as Perrin loosed. Slayer vanished, appearing on the ground a short distance away - and Hopper leaped on him from above, pulling him to the ground. Slayer cursed with a guttural sound, then vanished.

hɪɹ, hɑpɝ sɛnt, ʃoʊɪŋ ə hɪlsaɪd.

Here, Hopper sent, showing a hillside.

pɛɹɪn wɑz ðəɹ ɪn ən ɪnstənt, hæmɝ ɪn ɪz hænz, ðə pæk wɪð hɪm. sleɪɝ ɹeɪzd ə sɔɹɾ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ə naɪf ɪn ði ʌðɝ əz pɛɹɪn ən ðə fɔɹ wʊlvz ətækt.

Perrin was there in an instant, hammer in his hands, the pack with him. Slayer raised a sword in one hand and a knife in the other as Perrin and the four wolves attacked.

pɛɹɪn hɪt fɝst, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ wɪð ə ɹɔɹ. sleɪɝ æktʃəli  sæŋk ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ lɪkwəd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ bɪniθ ði æks bloʊ. hi ɹæmd ɪz naɪf fɔɹwɝd  - pɪɹsɪŋ oʊk dænsɝz bɹɛst wɪð ə splæʃ ə skɑɹlət blʌɾ əz i swʌŋ tə ðə saɪd, slæʃɪŋ əkɹɔs spɑɹks' feɪs. oʊk dænsɝ dɪdnt ɡɛt taɪm tə haʊl; ʃi kəlæps tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən sleɪɝ vænɪʃt əz pɛɹɪn bɹɔɾ ɪz hæmɝ bæk ɝaʊnd.

Perrin hit first, swinging his hammer with a roar. Slayer actually sank into the ground, as if it were liquid, dropping beneath the axe blow. He rammed his knife forward  - piercing Oak Dancer's breast with a splash of scarlet blood as he swung to the side, slashing across Sparks' face. Oak Dancer didn't get time to howl; she collapsed to the ground, and Slayer vanished as Perrin brought his hammer back around.

wɪmpɝɪŋ, spɑɹks sɛn æɡəni ən pænɪk ən vænɪʃt. hi wəd lɪv. bʌɾ oʊk dænsɝ wɑz dɛd.

Whimpering, Sparks sent agony and panic and vanished. He would live. But Oak Dancer was dead.

sleɪɝz sɛn hæd bɪn ðɪs pleɪs əɡɛn. pɛɹɪn tɝn tə smæʃ ɪz hæmɝ ɪndə sleɪɝz sɔɹɾ əz ɪt sɔt tə pɪɹs ɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. əɡɛn ə lʊk ə sɝpɹaɪz fɹəm sleɪɝ. ðə mæn bɛɹɾ ɪz tiθ, pʊlɪŋ bæk, kipɪŋ ə wɛɹi aɪ ɑn ðə tu ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ wʊlvz, hɑpɝ ən baʊnləs. sleɪɝz fɔɹɑɹm wɑz bliɾɪŋ wɛɹ hɑpɝ hæd bɪɾən hɪm.

Slayer's scent had been this place again. Perrin turned to smash his hammer into Slayer's sword as it sought to pierce him from behind. Again a look of surprise from Slayer. The man bared his teeth, pulling back, keeping a wary eye on the two remaining wolves, Hopper and Boundless. Slayer's forearm was bleeding where Hopper had bitten him.

"haʊ ɪz ðə doʊm kɹieɪɾəd, luk?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ʃoʊ mi ən liv. əl lɛt jə dɪpɑɹt."

"How is the dome created, Luc?" Perrin said. "Show me and leave. I will let you depart."

"boʊld wɝdz, kʌb," sleɪɝ snɑɹəl bæk. "fɔɹ wʌn u dʒʌst wɑtʃt mi kɪl wʌn ə jəɹ pæk."

"Bold words, cub," Slayer snarled back. "For one who just watched me kill one of your pack."

baʊnləs haʊld ɪn æŋɡɝ, lipɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. pɛɹɪn ətækt ət ðə seɪm taɪm, bʌt ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ əm tʃɹɛmbəld, ʃeɪkɪŋ.

Boundless howled in anger, leaping forward. Perrin attacked at the same time, but the ground beneath them trembled, shaking.

noʊ, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hɪz oʊn fʊɾɪŋ bɪkeɪm fɝm əz baʊnləs wɑz nɑk tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

No, Perrin thought. His own footing became firm as Boundless was knocked to the ground.

sleɪɝ lʌnʒd, ən pənɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hæmɝ tə blɑk - bʌt sleɪɝz wɛpən tɝn ɪndə smoʊk ən pæst ɹaɪt θɹu ɪt, səlɪɾəfaɪɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. wɪð ə jɛlp, pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl bæk, bʌt ðə bleɪd skɔɹɾ ɪm əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst, kʌɾɪŋ θɹu hɪz ʃɝɾ ən livɪŋ ə ɡæʃ fɹəm wʌn ɑɹm tə ði ʌðɝ. ɪt flɛɹd wɪð peɪn.

Slayer lunged, and Penin raised his hammer to block - but Slayer's weapon turned into smoke and passed right through it, solidifying on the other side. With a yelp, Perrin tried to pull back, but the blade scored him across the chest, cutting through his shirt and leaving a gash from one arm to the other. It flared with pain.

pɛɹɪn ɡæspt, stʌmbəlɪŋ bækwɝd. sleɪɝ dʒɹoʊv fɔɹwɝd, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ kɹæʃt ɪndə hɪm fɹəm əbʌv. hɑpɝ. wʌns əɡɛn ðə ɡɹɪzəld wʊlf bɔɹ sleɪɝ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ, fæŋz flæʃɪŋ.

Perrin gasped, stumbling backward. Slayer drove forward, but something crashed into him from above. Hopper. Once again the grizzled wolf bore Slayer to the ground, growling, fangs flashing.

sleɪɝ kɝst ən kɪk ðə wʊlf fɹi. hɑpɝ wɛn flaɪɪŋ wɪð ə wɪmpɝ ə peɪn, tɔst səm twɛnti fit. tə ðə saɪd, baʊnləs hæd kɑz ði ɝθ tə stɑp ɹʌmbəlɪŋ, bʌt hæd hɝɾ ɪz pɔ.

Slayer cursed and kicked the wolf free. Hopper went flying with a whimper of pain, tossed some twenty feet. To the side, Boundless had caused the earth to stop rumbling, but had hurt his paw.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf fɹi ʌv ɪz peɪn. sleɪɝ wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ ðɪs wɝld. pɛɹɪnz hæmɝ fɛl slʌɡɪʃ wɛnɛvɝ i swʌŋ, əz ɪf ði ɛɹ ɪtsɛlf wɝ θɪkɝ.

Perrin shook himself free of his pain. Slayer was strong in control over this world. Perrin's hammer felt sluggish whenever he swung, as if the air itself were thicker.

sleɪɝ hæd smaɪld wən hid kɪld oʊk dænsɝ. pɛɹɪn muv fɔɹwɝd, ɛnɹeɪdʒd. sleɪɝ wɑz ɑn ɪz hɛɾ ən ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ bæk daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd, təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz. pɛɹɪn tʃeɪst æftɝ hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪz waʊnd. ɪt wɑzn bæɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑp hɪm, ðoʊ hi dɪɾ ɪmædʒən ə bændɪdʒ ɪn pleɪs ɑn ɪt, hɪz kloʊðɪŋ mɛndɪɾ ən taɪɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛs tə stæntʃ ðə blʌd.

Slayer had smiled when he'd killed Oak Dancer. Perrin moved forward, enraged. Slayer was on his het and retreating back down the hillside, toward the trees. Perrin chased after him, ignoring his wound. It wasn't bad enough to stop him, though he did imagine a bandage in place on it, his clothing mended and tight against his chest to stanch the blood.

hi ɛntɝd ðə tʃɹiz dʒʌs bɪhaɪn sleɪɝ. ðə bɹæntʃəz kloʊzd oʊvɝhɛd, ən vaɪnz wɪp fɹəm ðə dɑɹkənd ʃædoʊz. pɛɹɪn dɪdn bɑðɝ faɪɾɪŋ əm ɔf. vaɪnz dɪdn muv laɪk ðæt. ðeɪ kʊdn tʌtʃ hɪm. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, əz sun əz ðeɪ ɡɹu kloʊs, ðeɪ wɪðɝɾ ən fɛl stɪl.

He entered the trees just behind Slayer. The branches closed overhead, and vines whipped from the darkened shadows. Perrin didn't bother fighting them off. Vines didn't move like that. They couldn't touch him. Sure enough, as soon as they grew close, they withered and fell still.

sleɪɝ kɝst, ðən bɪɡæn tə muv ɪn bɝstɪŋ stɛps, livɪŋ ə blɝ bɪhaɪn hɪm. pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, ɛnhænsɪŋ ɪz oʊn spid.

Slayer cursed, then began to move in bursting steps, leaving a blur behind him. Perrin followed, enhancing his own speed.

pɛɹɪn dɪdn kɑnʃəsli meɪk ðə dɪsɪʒən tə dʒɹɑp tə fɔɹ lɛɡz, bʌɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbiɾ i hæd dʌn soʊ, tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ sleɪɝ əz hid hʌntəd ðə waɪt stæɡ.

Perrin didn't consciously make the decision to drop to four legs, but in a heartbeat he had done so, chasing after Slayer as he'd hunted the white stag.

sleɪɝ wɑz fæst, bʌɾ i wɑz mɪɹli ə mæn. jʌŋ bʊl wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə læn ɪtsɛlf, ðə tʃɹiz, ðə bɹʌʃ, ðə stoʊnz, ðə ɹɪvɝz. hi muv θɹu ðə fɔɹəs laɪk ə bɹiz bloʊɪŋ θɹu ə hɑloʊ, kipɪŋ peɪs wɪð sleɪɝ ɡeɪnɪŋ ɑn hɪm. itʃ lɔɡ ɪn sleɪɝz weɪ wɑz ən əbstʃɹʌkʃən, bʌt tə jʌŋ bʊl itʃ wɑz dʒʌst ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæθweɪ.

Slayer was fast, but he was merely a man. Young Bull was part of the land itself, the trees, the brush, the stones, the rivers. He moved through the forest like a breeze blowing through a hollow, keeping pace with Slayer gaining on him. Each log in Slayer's way was an obstruction, but to Young Bull each was just a part of the pathway.

jʌŋ bʊl lɛp tə ðə saɪd, pɔz əɡɛns ðə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋks pʊʃɪŋ ɪm wən i tɝnd. hi sɔɹd, oʊvɝ stoʊnz ən ɹɑks, lipɪŋ fɹəm wʌn tə ðə nɛkst, livɪŋ ə blɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Young Bull leaped to the side, paws against the tree trunks pushing him when he turned. He soared, over stones and rocks, leaping from one to the next, leaving a blur in the air behind him.

sleɪɝ smɛld əfɹeɪd fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. hi vænɪʃt, bʌt jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd, əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə fild wɛɹ ði ɑɹmi kæmpt, bɪniθ ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn sɔɹd. sleɪɝ lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən kɝst, vænɪʃɪŋ əɡɛn.

Slayer smelled afraid for the first time. He vanished, but Young Bull followed, appearing in the field where the army camped, beneath the shadow of the large stone sword. Slayer looked over his shoulder and cursed, vanishing again.

jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd. ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd meɪd kæmp.

Young Bull followed. The place where the Whitecloaks had made camp.

ðə tɑp ʌv ə smɔl plætoʊ.

The top of a small plateau.

ə kævɝn bɝoʊɾ ɪndə ə hɪlsaɪd.

A cavern burrowed into a hillside.

ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə smɔl leɪk. jʌŋ bʊl ɹæn əpɑn ðə sɝfəs wɪð iz.

The middle of a small lake. Young Bull ran upon the surface with ease.

itʃ pleɪs sleɪɝ wɛnt, hi fɑloʊd, itʃ moʊmənt ɡɹoʊɪŋ kloʊsɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ sɔɹdz, hæmɝz, əɹ baʊz. ðɪs wɑz ə tʃeɪs, ən jʌŋ bʊl wɑz ðə hʌntɝ ðɪs taɪm. hi -  hi lɛpt ɪndə ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə fild, ən sleɪɝ wɑzn ðɛɹ. hi smɛld wɛɹ ðə mæn hæd ɡɔn, haʊɛvɝ. hi fɑloʊd hɪm, ən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ənʌðɝ pleɪs ɑn ðə seɪm fild. ðəɹ wɝ sɛns ə pleɪsəz ɔl ɝaʊnd. wʌt?

Each place Slayer went, he followed, each moment growing closer. There was no time for swords, hammers, or bows. This was a chase, and Young Bull was the hunter this time. He -  He leaped into the middle of a field, and Slayer wasn't there. He smelled where the man had gone, however. He followed him, and appeared in another place on the same field. There were scents of places all around. What?

pɛɹɪn keɪm tə ə stɑp, buɾɪd fit ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi spʌn, bɪwɪldɝd. sleɪɝ mʌst əv hɑp kwɪkli θɹu sɛvɹəl dɪfɹən pleɪsəz ɪn ðə seɪm fild, kənfjuzɪŋ ɪz tʃɹeɪl. pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə dətɝmən wɪtʃ wʌn tə fɑloʊ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl feɪɾəd ən ɪntɝmɪkst.

Perrin came to a stop, booted feet grinding into the ground. He spun, bewildered. Slayer must have hopped quickly through several different places in the same field, confusing his trail. Perrin tried to determine which one to follow, but they all faded and intermixed.

"bɝn hɪm!" hi sɛd.

"Burn him!" he said.

jʌŋ bʊl, ə sɛndɪŋ keɪm. spɑɹks. ðə wʊlf hæd bɪn wundəd, bʌɾ i hædn flɛɾ əz pɛɹɪn hæɾ əsumd. hi sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ə θɪn sɪlvɝ ɹɑd, tu hændspænz haɪ, spɹaʊɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə stæn ə dɔɡfɛnəl.

Young Bull, a sending came. Sparks. The wolf had been wounded, but he hadn't fled as Perrin had assumed. He sent an image of a thin silver rod, two handspans high, sprouting from the ground in the middle of a stand of dogfennel.

pɛɹɪn smaɪld ən sɛn hɪmsɛlf ðɛɹ. ðə wundəd wʊlf, stɪl tʃɹeɪlɪŋ blʌd, leɪ bɪsaɪd ði ɑbʒɛkt. ɪt wɑz ɑbviəsli səm sɔɹɾ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ɪt pɪɹd tə bi meɪɾ ə dʌzənz əpɑn dʌzənz ə faɪn, waɪɹlaɪk bɪts ə mɛɾəl woʊvən təɡɛðɝ laɪk ə bɹeɪd. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt tu hændspænz lɔŋ, ən wɑz dʒɹɪvən pɔɪn fɝst ɪndə ðə sɑft ɝθ.

Perrin smiled and sent himself there. The wounded wolf, still trailing blood, lay beside the object. It was obviously some sort of ter'angreal. it ppeared to be made of dozens upon dozens of fine, wirelike bits of metal woven together like a braid. It was about two handspans long, and was driven point first into the soft earth.

pɛɹɪn pʊld ɪt fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə doʊm dɪdn vænɪʃ. hi tɝn ðə spaɪk oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz hænd, bʌt hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ tə meɪk ðə doʊm stɑp. hi wɪl ðə spaɪk tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ə stɪk, ən wɑz ʃɑkt wən i wɑz ɹɪbʌft. ði ɑbʒɛkt æktʃəli  sim tə pʊʃ ɪz maɪn əweɪ.

Perrin pulled it from the ground. The dome didn't vanish. He turned the spike over in his hand, but had no idea how to make the dome stop. He willed the spike to change into something else, a stick, and was shocked when he was rebuffed. The object actually seemed to push his mind away.

ɪts hɪɹ ɪn ɪts ɹiæləɾi, spɑɹks sɛnt. ðə sɛndɪŋ tʃɹaɪd tə kənveɪ sʌmθɪŋ, ðət ði aɪɾəm wɑz sʌmhaʊ mɔɹ ɹil ðən moʊs θɪŋz ɪn ðə dʒɹim wɝld.

It is here in its reality, Sparks sent. The sending tried to convey something, that the item was somehow more real than most things in the dream world.

pɛɹɪn dɪdn əv taɪm tə wʌndɝ əbaʊɾ ɪt. fɝs pɹaɪɔɹəɾi wɑz tə muv ðə doʊm, ɪf i kʊd, əweɪ fɹəm wɛɹ ɪz pipəl kæmpt. hi sɛn hɪmsɛlf tə ði ɛdʒ wɛɹ hiɾ ɛntɝd ðə doʊm.

Perrin didn't have time to wonder about it. First priority was to move the dome, if he could, away from where his people camped. He sent himself to the edge where he'd entered the dome.

əz hid hoʊpt, ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə doʊm muvd wɪð hɪm. hi wɑz ət ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hiɾ ɛntɝd, bʌt ði ɛdʒ ə ðə doʊm hæd tʃeɪnʒd pəzɪʃənz, ðə sɛntɝ fɔlɪŋ wɛɹɛvɝ pɛɹɪn wɑz stændɪŋ. ðə doʊm stɪl dɑməneɪɾəd ðə skaɪ, ɪkstɛndɪŋ fɑɹ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən.

As he'd hoped, the center of the dome moved with him. He was at the place where he'd entered, but the edge of the dome had changed positions, the center falling wherever Perrin was standing. The dome still dominated the sky, extending far in every direction.

jʌŋ bʊl, spɑɹks sɛnt. aɪm fɹi. ðə ɹɔŋɡnəs ɪz ɡɔn.

Young Bull, Sparks sent. I am free. The wrongness is gone.

ɡoʊ, pɛɹɪn sɛnt. əl teɪk ðɪs ən ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt. itʃ ə ju, ɡoʊ ə dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃən ən haʊl.

Go, Perrin sent. I'll take this and get rid of it. Each of you, go a different direction and howl.

kənfjuz sleɪɝ.

Confuse Slayer.

ðə wʊlvz ɹɪspɑndɪd. ə pɑɹɾ ə pɛɹɪn, ðə hʌntɝ ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm, wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd ət nɑt hævɪŋ bɪn eɪbəl tə dɪfit sleɪɝ dɝɛkli. bʌt ðɪs wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

The wolves responded. A part of Perrin, the hunter inside of him, was frustrated at not having been able to defeat Slayer directly. But this was more important.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃɪf tə sʌmpleɪs dɪstənt, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdnt wɝk. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðəɾ ivən ðoʊ hi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, hi wɑz stɪl baʊn baɪ ðə doʊmz ɹulz.

He tried to shift to someplace distant, but it didn't work. It appeared that even though he was holding the ter'angreal, he was still bound by the dome's rules.

soʊ, ɪnstɛd, hi ʃɪftəɾ əz fɑɹ əz i kʊd. nil hæd sɛɾ ɪt wɑz əbaʊt fɔɹ liɡz fɹəm ðɛɹ kæmp tə ðə pɝɪməɾɝ, soʊ pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəd ðət fɑɹ tə ðə nɔɹθ, ðən dɪd soʊ əɡɛn, ən əɡɛn. ði ɪnɔɹməs doʊm muvd wɪð hɪm, ɪts sɛntɝ ɔlweɪz əpɪɹɪŋ dɝɛkli oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd.

So, instead, he shifted as far as he could. Neald had said it was about four leagues from their camp to the perimeter, so Perrin shifted that far to the north, then did so again, and again. The enormous dome moved with him, its center always appearing directly over his head.

hi wəd teɪk ðə spaɪk sʌmpleɪs seɪf, sʌmpleɪs wɛɹ sleɪɝ kʊdn faɪn ɪt.

He would take the spike someplace safe, someplace where Slayer couldn't find it.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɪks


CHAPTER 36

ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən


An Invitation

ɛɡwin əpɪɹɾ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wɛɹɪŋ ə pjʊɹ waɪt ɡaʊn soʊn wɪð ɡoʊldən θɹɛɾ ət ðə simz ən ɪn ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, taɪni bɪts ʌv əbsɪɾiən - pɑlɪʃt bʌɾ ənʃeɪpt - soʊn ɪn ɡoʊld əlɔŋ ðə tʃɹɪm ə ðə bɑɾəs. ə tɛɹəbli ɪmpɹæktəkəl dʒɹɛs tə oʊn, bʌt ðət dɪdn mæɾɝ hɪɹ.

Egwene appeared in Tel'aran'rhiod wearing a pure white gown sewn with golden thread at the seams and in the embroidery, tiny bits of obsidian - polished but unshaped - sewn in gold along the trim of the bodice. A terribly impractical dress to own, but that didn't matter here.

ʃi wɑz ɪn əɹ tʃeɪmbɝz, wɛɹ ʃid wɑntəd tə əpɪɹ. ʃi sɛn hɝsɛlf tə ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑz kɔɹɾɝz. nɪneɪiv wɑz ðɛɹ, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, hɝ dʒɹɛs ə fɑɹ mɔɹ sɛnsəbəl tæn ən bɹaʊn.

She was in her chambers, where she'd wanted to appear. She sent herself to the hallway outside the Yellow Ajah's quarters. Nynaeve was there, arms folded, her dress a far more sensible tan and brown.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə bi vɛɹi kɛɹfəl," ɛɡwin sɛd. "jɔɹ ði oʊnli wʌn hɪɹ u hæz feɪst wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən dɝɛkli, ən jə ɔlsoʊ hæv mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd ðən ði ʌðɝz. ɪf mɛsænə ɝaɪvz, jə ɑɹ tə lid ði ətæk."

"I want you to be very careful," Egwene said. "You're the only one here who has faced one of the Forsaken directly, and you also have more experience with Tel'aran'rhiod than the others. If Mesaana arrives, you are to lead the attack."

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən mænədʒ ðæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ maʊθ ɹaɪzɪŋ. jɛs, ʃi kəd mænədʒ ɪt. hoʊldɪŋ nɪneɪiv bæk fɹəm ətækɪŋ, ðət wʊɾə bɪn ðə dɪfəkəl tæsk.

"I think I can manage that," Nynaeve said, the corners of her mouth rising. Yes, she could manage it. Holding Nynaeve back from attacking, that would have been the difficult task.

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, ən nɪneɪiv vænɪʃt. ʃid ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən nɪɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ mɛsænə əɹ blæk sɪstɝz kʌmɪŋ tə spaɪ ɑn ðə dəkɔɪ miɾɪŋ hæpənɪŋ ðɛɹ. ɛɡwin sɛn hɝsɛlf tə ənʌðɝ pleɪs ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ə hɔl wɛɹ ðə tʃɹu miɾɪŋ wəd teɪk pleɪs bɪtwin hɝsɛlf, ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz.

Egwene nodded, and Nynaeve vanished. She'd remain hidden near the Hall of the Tower, watching for Mesaana or Black sisters coming to spy on the decoy meeting happening there. Egwene sent herself to another place in the city, a hall where the true meeting would take place between herself, the Wise Ones and the Windfinders.

tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd sɛvɹəl miɾɪŋ hɔlz juz fəɹ mjuzɪkəl pɝfɔɹmənsəz əɹ fəɹ ɡæðɝɪŋz. ðɪs wʌn, noʊn əz ðə mjuzɪʃənz weɪ, wɑz pɝfək fəɹ əɹ nidz. ɪt wɑz pɹɪsaɪsli dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð lɛðɝlif wʊd pænəlɪŋ kɑɹv tə lʊk laɪk ə fɔɹəst ə tʃɹiz laɪnɪŋ ðə wɔlz. ðə tʃɛɹz wɝ ʌv ə mætʃɪŋ wʊd, sʌŋ baɪ oʊɡiɝ, itʃ wʌn ə θɪŋ ə bjuɾi.

Tar Valon had several meeting halls used for musical performances or for gatherings. This one, known as the Musician's Way, was perfect for her needs. It was precisely decorated with leatherleaf wood paneling carved to look like a forest of trees lining the walls. The chairs were of a matching wood, sung by Ogier, each one a thing of beauty.

ðeɪ wɝ ɝeɪnʒd ɪn ðə ɹaʊnd, feɪsɪŋ ə sɛntʃɹəl poʊɾiəm. ðə doʊm silɪŋ wɑz ɪnsɛt wɪð mɑɹbəl kɑɹv tə lʊk laɪk stɑɹz ɪn ðə skaɪ. ði ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl; bjuɾəfəl wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ɡɔɾi.

They were arranged in the round, facing a central podium. The domed ceiling was inset with marble carved to look like stars in the sky. The ornamentation was remarkable; beautiful without being gaudy.

ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɝaɪvd - æmɪz, bɛɹ ən məleɪn, huz bɛli wɑz ɡɹeɪt wɪð ðə leɪɾɝ steɪdʒəz ə pɹɛɡnənsi. ðɪs æmfəθiəɾɝ hæɾ ə ɹeɪz plætfɔɹm əlɔŋ wʌn saɪd wɛɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz kəd sɪt kʌmfɝɾəbli ɑn ðə flɔɹ, jɛt ðoʊz siɾəd ɪn ðə tʃɛɹz wəd nɑt lʊk daʊn ət ðɛm.

The Wise Ones had already arrived - Amys, Bair and Melaine, whose belly was great with the later stages of pregnancy. This amphitheater had a raised platform along one side where the Wise Ones could sit comfortably on the floor, yet those seated in the chairs would not look down at them.

lin, jukɪɝi ən sin sæɾ ɪn tʃɛɹz feɪsɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz, itʃ wɛɹɪŋ wʌn ʌv ɪleɪnz kɑpid dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil, lʊkɪŋ ʃæɾoʊi ən ɪnsəbstæntʃəl. ɪleɪn wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ðɛɹ, tu, bʌt ʃi hæd wɔɹnd ʃi maɪɾ əv tʃɹʌbəl tʃænəlɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ɛntɝ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

Leane, Yukiri and Seaine sat in chairs facing the Wise Ones, each wearing one of Elayne's copied dream ter'angreal, looking shadowy and insubstantial. Elayne was supposed to be there, too, but she had warned she might have trouble channeling enough to enter Tel'aran'rhiod.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz ɪnspɛktɪd wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð ə nɪɹli pælpəbəl ɛɹ ə hɑstɪləɾi. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kənsɪɾɝd ðə waɪz wʌnz tə bi pʊɹli tʃɹeɪnd waɪldɝz; ðə waɪz wʌnz, ɪn tɝn, θɔt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fʊl ə ðɛmsɛlvz.

The Aes Sedai and Wise Ones inspected one another with a nearly palpable air of hostility. The Aes Sedai considered the Wise Ones to be poorly trained wilders; the Wise Ones, in turn, thought the Aes Sedai full of themselves.

əz ɛɡwin ɝaɪvd, ə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən wɪð dɑɹk skɪn ən blæk hɛɹ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum. ðə wɪndndɝz ɡlænst əbaʊt səspɪʃəsli. sɪuən hæd sɛd, fɹəm əɹ taɪm titʃɪŋ ðɛm, ðət ðə si foʊk hæd lɛdʒənz əbaʊt tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ ən ɪts deɪnʒɝz. ðət hædn stɑp ðə wɪndndɝz fɹəm lɝnɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ kəɾ əbaʊt ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz ðə moʊmən ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɹil.

As Egwene arrived, a group of women with dark skin and black hair appeared in the very center of the room. The Windhnders glanced about suspiciously. Siuan had said, from her time teaching them, that the Sea Folk had legends about Tel'aran'rhiod and its dangers. That hadn't stopped the Windhnders from learning everything they could about the World of Dreams the moment they discovered that it was real.

ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə wɪndndɝz wɑz ə tɔl, slɛndɝ wʊmən wɪð nɛɹoʊ aɪz ən ə lɔŋ nɛk, numɝəs mədæljənz ɑn ðə faɪn tʃeɪn kənɛktɪŋ əɹ noʊz tə hɝ lɛft ɪɹ. ðət wəd bi ʃilɪn, wʌn ə ðoʊz nɪneɪiv hæd toʊld ɛɡwin əbaʊt. ðə θɹi ʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝz ɪnkluɾəd ə dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən wɪð waɪt lɑks ə hɛɹ woʊvən əmʌŋ əɹ blæk. ðət wəd bi ɹɪneɪl, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə lɛɾɝz ðeɪd sɛn ən nɪneɪivz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn lɛd tə bɪliv ʃid bi fɔɹmoʊst əmʌŋ ðɛm, bʌt ʃi sim səbsɝviən tə ði ʌðɝz. hæd ʃi lɔst əɹ pleɪs əz wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps?

At the head of the Windhnders was a tall, slender woman with narrow eyes and a long neck, numerous medallions on the fine chain connecting her nose to her left ear. That would be Shielyn, one of those Nynaeve had told Egwene about. The three other Windfinders included a dignified woman with white locks of hair woven among her black. That would be Renaile, according to the letters they'd sent and Nynaeve's instruction. Egwene had been led to believe she'd be foremost among them, but she seemed subservient to the others. Had she lost her place as Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships?

"wɛlkəm," ɛɡwin sɛd tə ðɛm. "pliz, sɪt." wɪl stænd," ʃilɪn sɛd. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz tɛns.

"Welcome," Egwene said to them. "Please, sit." We will stand," Shielyn said. Her voice was tense.

'hu ɑɹ ðiz wʌnz, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ?" æmɪz æskt. "tʃɪlʒɹən ʃəd nɑt bi vɪzəɾɪŋ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ɪts nɑɾ ən əbændən sænd-bædʒɝz dɛn tə bi ɪksplɔɹd."

'Who are these ones, Egwene al'Vere?" Amys asked. "Children should not be visiting Tel'aran'rhiod. It is not an abandoned sand-badger's den to be explored."

"tʃɪlʒɹən?" ʃilɪn æskt.

"Children?" Shielyn asked.

"ju ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən hɪɹ, wɛtləndɝ."

"You are children here, wetlander."

"æmɪz, pliz," ɛɡwin kʌɾ ɪn. "aɪ lɛn əm tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə kʌm hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi."

"Amys, please," Egwene cut in. "I lent them ter'angreal to come here. It was necessary."

"wi cʊɾə mɛɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz," bɛɹ sɛd. "tʃuzɪŋ ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə bæɾəlfild maɪɾ əv bɪn seɪfɝ."

"We could have met outside the World of Dreams," Bair said. "Choosing the middle of a battlefield might have been safer."

ɪndid, ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ vɛɹi ʌnfəmɪljɝ wɪð ðə wɝkɪŋz ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ðɛɹ bɹaɪt kloʊðɪŋ piɹiɑɾɪkəli tʃeɪnʒd kʌlɝz - ɪn fækt, əz ɛɡwin wɑtʃt, ɹɪneɪlz blaʊs vænɪʃt ɪntaɪɝli. ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf blʌʃɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪleɪn hæd mɛnʃən ðət wən ɑn ðə weɪvz, si foʊk mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ wɝkt wɛɹɪŋ nɑɾ ə stɪtʃ əbʌv ðə weɪs ðə blaʊs wɑz bæk ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ. ðɛɹ dʒuəlɹi ɔlsoʊ simd ɪn ɔlmoʊs kɑnstən flʌks.

Indeed, the Windfinders were very unfamiliar with the workings of Tel'aran'rhiod. Their bright clothing periodically changed colors - in fact, as Egwene watched, Renaile's blouse vanished entirely. Egwene found herself blushing, though Elayne had mentioned that when on the waves, Sea Folk men and women both worked wearing not a stitch above the waist The blouse was back a moment later. Their jewelry also seemed in almost constant flux.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɹizənz aɪ hæv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ hæv dʌn, æmɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ən siɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "ʃilɪn dɪn sæbʊɹə naɪt wɔɾɝz ən əɹ sɪstɝz əv bɪn toʊld ə ðə deɪnʒɝz ə ðɪs pleɪs, ən əv æksɛptɪd ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn seɪfti."

"There are reasons I have done what I have done, Amys," Egwene said striding forward and seating herself. "Shielyn din Sabura Night Waters and her sisters have been told of the dangers of this place, and have accepted responsibility for their own safety."

"ə lɪɾəl laɪk ɡɪvɪŋ ə faɪɝbɹæn ən ə kæsk ʌv ɔɪl tə ə tʃaɪld," məleɪn mʌɾɝd, "æn kleɪmɪŋ juv ɡɪvən ɪm ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ɪz oʊn seɪfti."

"A little like giving a firebrand and a cask of oil to a child," Melaine muttered, "and claiming you've given him responsibility for his own safety."

"mʌst wi ɛndʒjʊɹ ðɪs skwɑbəlɪŋ, mʌðɝ?" jukɪɝi æskt.

"Must we endure this squabbling, Mother?" Yukiri asked.

ɛɡwin tʊk ə kɑmɪŋ bɹɛθ. "pliz, jə ɑɹ liɾɝz ə jəɹ sɛpɹət pipəlz, wɪmən wɪð ɹɛpjəteɪʃənz fəɹ ɡɹeɪt wɪzdəm ən əkjuəɾi. kən wi nɑɾ ət lis bi sɪvəl wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ?" ɛɡwin tɝn tə ðə si foʊk. "wɪnd-faɪndɝ ʃilɪn, juv æksɛptɪd maɪ ɪnvɪteɪʃən. ʃʊɹli jəl naʊ nɑt ɹɪdʒɛk maɪ hɑspətæləɾi baɪ stændɪŋ θɹu ði ɪntaɪɝ miɾɪŋ?"

Egwene took a calming breath. "Please, you are leaders of your separate peoples, women with reputations for great wisdom and acuity. Can we not at least be civil with one another?" Egwene turned to the Sea Folk. "Wind-finder Shielyn, you have accepted my invitation. Surely you will now not reject my hospitality by standing through the entire meeting?"

ðə wʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi hæɾ ə pɹaʊɾ ɛɹ tə hɝ; ɹisən ɪntɝækʃən bɪtwin ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə si foʊk hæd meɪɾ əɹ boʊld. ɛɡwin ʃʌv daʊn ə stæb ʌv æŋɡɝ; ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ðə dɪteɪlz ə ðə bɑɹɡən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə boʊl ʌv wɪnz. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ. ðeɪ -  noʊ. ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv hæd dʌn ðɛɹ bɛst, ən hæd bɪn ʌndɝ ənjuʒəwəl stʃɹeɪn. bɪsaɪdz, bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə si foʊk wɑz sɛd tə bi oʊnli wʌn stɛp seɪfɝ ðən bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf.

The woman hesitated. She had a proud air to her; recent interaction between the Aes Sedai and the Sea Folk had made her bold. Egwene shoved down a stab of anger; she did not like the details of the bargain regarding the Bowl of Winds. Nynaeve and Elayne should have known better. They -  No. Elayne and Nynaeve had done their best, and had been under unusual strain. ʃilɪn faɪnəli ɡeɪv ə kɝt nɑd, ðoʊ hɝ blaʊs tʃeɪnʒd kʌlɝz sɛvɹəl taɪmz waɪl ʃi kənsɪɾɝd, sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑn kɹɪmzən, ən əɹ dʒuəlɹi kɛp vænɪʃɪŋ ən ɹiəpɪɹɪŋ. Shielyn finally gave a curt nod, though her blouse changed colors several times while she considered, settling on crimson, and her jewelry kept vanishing and reappearing. "Very well. We are indebted to you for the gift of this place, and will agree to your hospitality." She sat down in a chair apart from Egwene and the other Aes Sedai, and those with her did as well.

ɛɡwin ɹilist ə sɑf bɹɛθ ə ɹɪlif ən sʌmən sɛvɹəl smɔl teɪbəlz wɪð kʌps ʌv wɔɹm, fɹeɪɡɹən ti. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz dʒʌmpt, ðoʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪdn bæɾ ən aɪ. æmɪz dɪd, haʊɛvɝ, ɹitʃ fəɹ əɹ kʌp ən tʃeɪnʒ ðə ɹoʊz-blɑsəm ti tə sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ə mʌtʃ dɑɹkɝ kæst.

Egwene released a soft breath of relief and summoned several small tables with cups of warm, fragrant tea. The Windfinders jumped, though the Wise Ones didn't bat an eye. Amys did, however, reach for her cup and change the rose-blossom tea to something with a much darker cast.

"pɝhæps jəl tɛl əs ðə pɝpəs ə ðɪs miɾɪŋ," bɛɹ sɛd, sɪpɪŋ əɹ ti. ðə si foʊk dɪd nɑt pɪk ʌp ðɛɹz, ðoʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd bɪɡæn tə dʒɹɪŋk.

"Perhaps you will tell us the purpose of this meeting," Bair said, sipping her tea. The Sea Folk did not pick up theirs, though the Aes Sedai did began to drink.

"wi hæv ɡɛst ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi," ʃilɪn sɛd. "ðɪs kɑnfɹənteɪʃən ɪz ɪn-ɛvɪɾəbəl, ðoʊ aɪ wɪʃ tə ðə wɪnz ðəɾ ɪt wɝ nɑt soʊ."

"We have guessed it already," Shielyn said. "This confrontation is in-evitable, though I wish to the winds that it were not so."

"wɛl, spik ʌp, ðɛn," jukɪɝi sɛd. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪɾ əbaʊt?"

"Well, speak up, then," Yukiri said. "What is it about?"

ʃilɪn foʊkəst ɑn ɛɡwin. "fɔɹ mɛni sizənz ən taɪdz wi hɪd ðə neɪtʃɝ ʌv əɹ wɪnfmdɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪnhəlz, bʌt dʌz nɑɾ ɪksheɪl - ðət wɪtʃ ɪz bɹɔɾ ɪn ɪz nɛvɝ əlaʊd tə liv. naʊ ðət jə noʊ ʌv ʌs, jə wɑn ʌs, fəɹ jə kænɑt stæn ðə θɔɾ ʌv wɪmən tʃænəlɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ə jəɹ ɡɹæsp."

Shielyn focused on Egwene. "For many seasons and tides we hid the nature of our Windfmding from the Aes Sedai. The White Tower inhales, but does not exhale - that which is brought in is never allowed to leave. Now that you know of us, you want us, for you cannot stand the thought of women channeling outside of your grasp."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹaʊnd. ɛɡwin kɑt məleɪn nɑɾɪŋ ɪn əɡɹimənt. ðə wɝdz wɝ tʃɹu ɪnʌf, ðoʊ oʊnli wʌn saɪɾ ə ði ɪʃu. ɪf ðeɪd noʊn haʊ jusfəl waɪt taʊɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wəd bi, ən haʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə pipəl tə noʊ ðət tʃænlɝz wɝ biɪŋ kɛɹd fəɹ ən tʃɹeɪnd . . .

The Aes Sedai frowned. Egwene caught Melaine nodding in agreement. The words were true enough, though only one side of the issue. If they'd known how useful White Tower training would be, and how important it was for the people to know that channelers were being cared for and trained . . .

haʊɛvɝ, ðət θɪŋkɪŋ fɛl hɑloʊ tə hɝ. ðə si foʊk hæd ðɛɹ oʊn tʃɹədɪʃənz, ən meɪd faɪn jus ə ðɛɹ tʃænlɝz wɪθaʊt ɹɛɡjəleɪʃən fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɛɡwin hædn spɛn əz mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð ðə si foʊk əz nɪneɪiv əɹ ɪleɪn, bʌt ʃid hæd dɪteɪld ɹɪpɔɹts. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ənskɪld wɪð mɛni wivz, bʌt ðɛɹ əbɪləɾiz wɪð spəsɪfɪk wivz -  pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðoʊz foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ɛɹ - wɝ fɑɹ mɔɹ ədvæns ðən ðoʊz pɹæktəs baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

However, that thinking felt hollow to her. The Sea Folk had their own traditions, and made fine use of their channelers without regulation from the White Tower. Egwene hadn't spent as much time with the Sea Folk as Nynaeve or Elayne, but she'd had detailed reports. The Windfinders were unskilled with many weaves, but their abilities with specific weaves -  particularly those focusing on Air - were far more advanced than those practiced by Aes Sedai.

ðiz wɪmən dɪzɝv ðə tʃɹuθ. wɑz ðət nɑt wʌt ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðə θɹi oʊðz, stʊd fɔɹ? "ju ɑɹ kɝɛkt, ʃilɪn dɪn sæbʊɹə naɪt wɔɾɝz " ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn jəɹ pipəl meɪ hæv bɪn waɪz tə kip ðɛɹ əbɪləɾiz hɪɾən fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

These women deserved the truth. Was that not what the White Tower, and the Three Oaths, stood for? "You are correct, Shielyn din Sabura Night Waters " Egwene said. "And your people may have been wise to keep their abilities hidden from the Aes Sedai."

jukɪɝi ɡæspt, ə kwaɪɾ ʌn-ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹiækʃən. ʃilɪn fɹoʊz, tʃeɪn fɹəm əɹ ɪɹ tə noʊz tɪŋkəlɪŋ sɔfli əz ðə mədæljənz ɑn ɪt hɪt təɡɛðɝ. hɝ blaʊs tʃeɪnʒd tə blu. "wʌt?"

Yukiri gasped, a quite un-Aes Sedai reaction. Shielyn froze, chain from her ear to nose tinkling softly as the medallions on it hit together. Her blouse changed to blue. "What?"

"ju meɪ hæv bɪn waɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ wəd nɑt pɹɪzum tə sɛkənd-ɡɛs ði æmɪɝlənz u keɪm bɪfɔɹ mi, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ən ɑɹɡjəmən tə bi meɪd. pɝhæps wɪv bɪn oʊvɝli zɛləs tə kəntʃɹoʊl wɪmən u kən wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪts ɑbviəs ðət ðə wɪndfɪndɝz əv dʌn wɛl ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəd lɝn mʌtʃ fɹəm ju."

Perhaps we have been overly zealous to control women who can wield the One Power. It is obvious that the Windfinders have done well in training themselves. I should think that the White Tower could learn much from you."

ʃilɪn sɛɾəld bæk, skænɪŋ ɛɡwinz feɪs. ɛɡwin mɛt ðə wʊmənz aɪz ən kɛpt əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən kɑm. si ðəɾ aɪm ɹɛzəlut, ʃi θɔt. si ðəɾ aɪ min wʌɾ aɪ seɪ. ðəɾ ɪz nɑt flæɾɝi. aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ. wʌn spik ðə tʃɹuθ.

"wɛl," ʃilɪn sɛd. "pɝhæps wi kəd meɪk ə bɑɹɡən ðət wəɾ əlaʊ əs tə tʃɹeɪn jəɹ wɪmən."

"Well," Shielyn said. "Perhaps we could make a bargain that would allow us to train your women."

ɛɡwin smaɪld. "aɪ wɑz hoʊpɪŋ ðət jə wəd si ði ædvæntɪdʒ ' ðæt." tə ðə saɪd, ðə θɹi ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɛɡwin wɪð mi-ʃʊɹd hɑstɪləɾi. wɛl, ðeɪ wəd si. ðə bɛst weɪ tə ɡeɪn ði ʌpɝ hænd wɑz tə ʃeɪk ɛkspɛkteɪʃənz laɪk ɹɪndwɔɾɝ biɾəlz ɪn ə dʒɑɹ.

ðoʊz u bɑɹɡənd wɪð jə ətʃiv sʌmθɪŋ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd."

Those who bargained with you achieved something unexpected."

tʃɹu wɝdz, ɛvɹi wʌn. haʊɛvɝ, ðə weɪ ʃi sɛɾ əm ɪmplaɪd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ - ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd wɑntəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə bi sɛn tə ðə si foʊk ʃɪps. ʃilɪnz fɹaʊn dipənd, ən ʃi sæt bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. ɛɡwin hoʊpt ʃi wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wɛðɝ əɹ pipəlz ɡɹæn vɪktɝi oʊvɝ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz hæd bɪn ə sɛtʌp fɹəm ðə stɑɹt.

True words, every one. However, the way she said them implied something more - that Egwene had wanted the Aes Sedai to be sent to the Sea Folk ships. Shielyn's frown deepened, and she sat back in her chair. Egwene hoped she was considering whether her people's grand victory over the Bowl of the Winds had been a setup from the start.

"ɪf ɛniθɪŋ," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud, "aɪ fil ðət ðə pɹiviəs əɡɹimənt wɑz nɑɾ æmbɪʃəs ɪnʌf."

"If anything," Egwene continued, "I feel that the previous agreement was not ambitious enough."

ʃi tɝn tə ðə waɪz wʌnz. "æmɪz, wəd jə əɡɹi ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæv nɑlədʒ ʌv wivz ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz də nɑt?"

"It would be foolish not to admit Aes Sedai expertise in these areas," Amys said carefully. "They spend much time practicing their weaves. But there are things we know that they do not."

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "dʊɹɪŋ maɪ taɪm tʃɹeɪnɪŋ bɪniθ ðə waɪz wʌnz, aɪ lɝn mɔɹ əbaʊt liɾɝʃɪp ðən aɪ dɪd dʊɹɪŋ maɪ taɪm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. jə ɔlsoʊ ɡeɪv mi vɛɹi hɛlpfəl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ ən dʒɹimɪŋ."
