"ɔl ɹaɪt," bɛɹ sɛd, "aʊt wɪð ɪt. wiv bɪn tʃeɪsɪŋ ə θɹi-lɛɡəd lɪzɝd ðɪs ɪntaɪɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, poʊkɪŋ ɪt wɪð ə stɪk tə si ɪf ɪɾəl muv ɛni fɝðɝ."

"All right," Bair said, "out with it. We've been chasing a three-legged lizard this entire conversation, poking it with a stick to see if it will move any further."

"wi nid tə ʃɛɹ wʌt wi noʊ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wi θɹi ɡɹups - wɪmən u kən tʃænəl - nid tə fɔɹm ən əlaɪəns."

"We need to share what we know with one another," Egwene said. "We three groups - women who can channel - need to form an alliance."

"wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl, aɪ əsum," ʃilɪn sɛd.

"With the White Tower in control, I assume," Shielyn said.

"ɔl aɪm seɪɪŋ," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd, "ɪz ðət ðəɹ ɪz wɪzdəm ɪn ʃɛɹɪŋ ən lɝnɪŋ fɹəm ʌðɝz.

"All I am saying," Egwene replied, "is that there is wisdom in sharing and learning from others.

waɪz wʌnz, aɪ wʊɾə æksɛptɪd fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ bi sɛn tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð ju. ɪt wəd bi pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli jusfəl tə hæv jə tʃɹeɪn əm tə mæstɝ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd"

Wise Ones, I would have Accepted from the White Tower be sent to train with you. It would be particularly useful to have you train them to master Tel'aran'rhiod"

ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðəɾ ənʌðɝ dʒɹimɝ, sətʃ əz ɛɡwin, wəd bi dɪskʌvɝɾ əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ ʃi kəd hoʊp. ðə tælənt wɑz vɛɹi ɹɛɹ. stɪl, ɪt wəd bi ædvənteɪdʒəs tə hæv səm sɪstɝz tʃɹeɪn ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪɾ əv tə ɛntɝ wɪð tɛɹæŋɡɹil.

It was unlikely that another Dreamer, such as Egwene, would be discovered among the Aes Sedai, though she could hope. The Talent was very rare. Still, it would be advantageous to have some sisters trained in Tel'aran'rhiod, even if they did have to enter with ter'angreal.

"wɪndfɪndɝz," ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud. "aɪ wəd sɛnd wɪmən tə jə əz wɛl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðoʊz skɪld ɪn ɛɹ, tə lɝn tə kɔl ðə wɪnz əz jə du."

"Windfinders," Egwene continued. "I would send women to you as well, particularly those skilled in Air, to learn to call the winds as you do."

"laɪf fəɹ ən əpɹɛntəs wɪndfɪndɝ ɪz nɑɾ izi," ʃilɪn sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ wɪmən wəd faɪn ɪt vɛɹi dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə sɑf laɪf ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"Life for an apprentice Windfinder is not easy," Shielyn said. "I think your women would find it very different from the soft life in the White Tower."

ɛɡwinz bæksaɪd stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə peɪn ə hɝ "sɑft" laɪf ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. "aɪ də nɑt daʊt ðəɾ ɪɾəl bi tʃælənʒɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt daʊt ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi vɛɹi hɛlpfəl fəɹ ðət vɛɹi ɹizən."

Egwene's backside still remembered the pain of her "soft" life in the White Tower. "I do not doubt that it will be challenging," she said, "but I do not doubt that it would be very helpful for that very reason."

"wɛl, aɪ səspɛk ðɪs kəd bi ɝeɪnʒd," ʃilɪn sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, saʊndɪŋ iɡɝ. "ðɛɹ wəɾ əv tə bi peɪmənt, ʌv kɔɹs."

"Well, I suspect this could be arranged," Shielyn said, leaning forward, sounding eager. "There would have to be payment, of course."

"æn ikwəl wʌn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪn əlaʊɪŋ jə tə sɛn səm ə jəɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð ʌs."

"An equal one," Egwene said. "In allowing you to send some of your apprentices to the White Tower to train with us."

"wi ɔlɹɛɾi sɛnd wɪmən tə ju."

"We already send women to you."

ɛɡwin snɪft. "toʊkən sækɹəfaɪsɪz sɛn soʊ wɪl nɑt bɪkʌm səspɪʃəs ə jəɹ wɪndfɪndɝz.

Egwene sniffed. "Token sacrifices sent so we will not become suspicious of your Windfinders.

jəɹ wɪmən ɔfən sɛklud ðɛmsɛlvz, əɹ kʌm ɹɪlʌktənli. aɪ wəɾ əv ðət pɹæktəs stɑp - ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɹizən tə dɪnaɪ pətɛnʃəl wɪndfɪndɝz tə jəɹ pipəl."

Your women often seclude themselves, or come reluctantly. I would have that practice stop - there is no reason to deny potential Windfinders to your people."

"wɛl, wʌt wəd bi ðə dɪfɝəns?" ʃilɪn æskt.

"Well, what would be the difference?" Shielyn asked.

"ðə wɪmən jə sɛnd wəd bi əlaʊd tə ɹɪtɝn tə jə æftɝ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "waɪz wʌnz, aɪ wəɾ əv il əpɹɛntəsɪz sɛn tə əs əz wɛl. nɑt ɹɪlʌktənli, ən nɑt tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt tə tʃɹeɪn ən lɝn əɹ weɪz. ðeɪ, tu, wəd bi əlaʊd tə ɹɪtɝn, ʃəd ðeɪ dɪzaɪɝ ɪt, wʌns ðeɪ ɑɹ fɪnɪʃt."

"The women you send would be allowed to return to you after their training," Egwene said. "Wise Ones, I would have Aiel apprentices sent to us as well. Not reluctantly, and not to become Aes Sedai, but to train and learn our ways. They, too, would be allowed to return, should they desire it, once they are finished."

"ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi mɔɹ ðən ðæt," æmɪz sɛd. "aɪ wɝi wʌt wəd hæpən tə wɪmən u bɪkʌm tu əkʌstəm tə sɑft wɛtləndɝ weɪz."

"It would have to be more than that," Amys said. "I worry what would happen to women who become too accustomed to soft wetlander ways."

"ʃʊɹli jə wʊdnt wɑnə kəmpɛl əm - " ɛɡwin bɪɡæn.

"Surely you wouldn't want to compel them - " Egwene began.

bɛɹ kʌɾ ɪn. "ðeɪd stɪl bi əpɹɛntəs waɪz wʌnz, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. tʃɪlʒɹən u nid tə kəmplit ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ən ðəɾ ɪz əsumɪŋ wi əɡɹi tə ðɪs plæn; sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ənsɛɾəlz maɪ stʌmək, laɪk tu mʌtʃ fuɾ æftɝ ə deɪ ʌv fæstɪŋ."

Bair cut in. "They'd still be apprentice Wise Ones, Egwene al'Vere. Children who need to complete their training. And that is assuming we agree to this plan; something about it unsettles my stomach, like too much food after a day of fasting."

"ɪf wi lɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛt hʊks ɪndə əɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz," məleɪn sɛd, ðəl nɑt sun bi pʊl fɹi."

"If we let the Aes Sedai set hooks into our apprentices," Melaine said, they will not soon be pulled free."

"du jə wɑn əm tə bi?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "du jə si wʌt juv ɪn mi, məleɪn? ən æmɪɝlɪn siɾ u wɑz tʃɹeɪn baɪ ði il? wʌt sækɹəfaɪs wəɾ ɪt bi wɝθ tə jəɹ pipəl tə hæv mɔɹ laɪk mi? ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ʌndɝstæn dʒiɾoʊ ən ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, hu ɹɪspɛkt waɪz wʌnz ɹæðɝ ðən siɪŋ əm əz ɹaɪvəlz əɹ waɪldɝz?"

"Do you want them to be?" Egwene said. "Do you see what you have in me, Melaine? An Amyrlin Seat who was trained by the Aiel? What sacrifice would it be worth to your people to have more like me? Aes Sedai who understand ji'e'toh and the Three-fold Land, who respect Wise Ones rather than seeing them as rivals or wilders?"

ðə θɹi il sɛɾəld bæk ət ðæt, lʊkɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, tʃɹʌbəld.

The three Aiel settled back at that, looking at one another, troubled.

"ænd wʌɾ ə ju, ʃilɪn?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌt wəɾ ɪt bi wɝθ tə jəɹ pipəl tə hæv ən æmɪɝlɪn sit hu, hævɪŋ tʃɹeɪnd wɪð ju, ɹɪɡɑɹdz jə əz fɹɛnz ən u ɹɪspɛks jəɹ weɪz?"

"And what of you, Shielyn?" Egwene said. "What would it be worth to your people to have an Amyrlin Seat who, having trained with you, regards you as friends and who respects your ways?"

"ðæt kəd bi væljəbəl," ʃilɪn ədmɪɾəd. "əsumɪŋ ðə wɪmən jə sɛn tə əs əv ə bɛɾɝ tɛmpɹəmən ðən ðoʊz hum wɪv sin soʊ fɑɹ. aɪ hæv jɛt tə miɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu kəd nɑt bɛnəfɪt fɹəm ə fju deɪz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə haɪ mæst."

"That could be valuable," Shielyn admitted. "Assuming the women you send to us have a better temperament than those whom we have seen so far. I have yet to meet an Aes Sedai who could not benefit from a few days hanging from the high mast."

"ðæɾ ɪz kəz jə ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɡɛɾɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd "hu ɑɹ sɛɾ ɪn ðɛɹ weɪz. ɪf wi wɝ tə sɛn jə æksɛptɪɾ ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ wəd bi mʌtʃ mɔɹ plaɪəbəl."

"That is because you insisted on getting Aes Sedai," Egwene said "who are set in their ways. If we were to send you Accepted instead, they would be much more pliable."

"ɪnstɛd?" ʃilɪn sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "ðɪs ɪz nɑt ðə bɑɹɡən wi wɝ dɪskʌsɪŋ."

"Instead?" Shielyn said immediately. "This is not the bargain we were discussing."

"ɪt kəd bi," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪf wi əlaʊ si foʊk tʃænlɝz tə ɹɪtɝn tə jə ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹikwaɪɝɪŋ ðət ðeɪ steɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, jəl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əv sətʃ ə stʃɹɔŋ niɾ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ titʃɝz."

"It could be," Egwene replied. "If we allow Sea Folk channelers to return to you instead of requiring that they stay in the Tower, you will no longer have such a strong need of the Aes Sedai teachers."

"ðɪs mʌs bi ə dɪfɹən əɡɹimənt." ʃilɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "æn ɪɾəl nɑt bi ə bɑɹɡən tə meɪk laɪtli. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ sɝpəns, laɪk ðoʊz ɹɪŋz jə wɛɹ."

"This must be a different agreement." Shielyn shook her head. "And it will not be a bargain to make lightly. Aes Sedai are serpents, like those rings you wear."

"wʌɾ ɪf aɪ ɔfɝ tə ɪnklud ðə dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil jə wɝ loʊnd?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"What if I offer to include the dream ter'angreal you were loaned?" Egwene asked.

ʃilɪn ɡlænst əɾ əɹ hænd wɛɹ, ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, ʃi wəd bi hoʊldɪŋ ðə smɔl pleɪt ðət -  wɪð ə tʃænəl bɪɾ ə spɪɹət - lɛɾ ə wʊmən ɛntɝ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ɛɡwin hædnt ɡɪvən əm ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət lɛt wʌn ɛntɝ wɪθaʊt niɾɪŋ tə tʃænəl, ʌv kɔɹs. ðoʊz wɝ mɔɹ vɝsəɾəl, ən ðɛɹfɔɹ mɔɹ paʊɝfəl. bɛs tə kip ðoʊz ə sikɹət.

Shielyn glanced at her hand where, in the real world, she would be holding the small plate that -  with a channeled bit of Spirit - let a woman enter Tel'aran'rhiod. Egwene hadn't given them the ter'angreal that let one enter without needing to channel, of course. Those were more versatile, and therefore more powerful. Best to keep those a secret.

"ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd" ɛɡwin sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, "ju kən ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ. jə kən mit ðoʊz u ɑɹ dɪstənt wɪθaʊt niɾɪŋ tə tʃɹævəl ðɛɹ, kən lɝn wʌɾ ɪz hɪɾən, ən kən kənfɝ ɪn sikɹət."

"In Tel'aran'rhiod" Egwene said, leaning forward, "you can go anywhere. You can meet those who are distant without needing to Travel there, can learn what is hidden, and can confer in secret."

"ðɪs ɪz ə deɪnʒɝəs θɪŋ jə sədʒɛst, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," æmɪz sɛd stɝnli. "tə lɛɾ əm lus wəd bi laɪk lɛɾɪŋ ə ɡɹup ʌv wɛtləndɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ɹʌn waɪld ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd."

"This is a dangerous thing you suggest, Egwene al'Vere," Amys said sternly. "To let them loose would be like letting a group of wetlander children run wild in the Three-fold Land."

"ju kænɑt kip ðɪs pleɪs fəɹ jɝsɛlf, æmɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"You cannot keep this place for yourself, Amys," Egwene said.

"wi ɑɹ nɑt soʊ sɛlfɪʃ," ðə waɪz wʌn sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz ðɛɹ seɪfti aɪ spik ʌv."

"We are not so selfish," the Wise One said. "It is their safety I speak of."

"ðɛn pɝhæps," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɪt wəd bi bɛst ɪf ðə si foʊk sɛn səm ə ðɛɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð jə waɪz wʌnz - ən pɝhæps jə kəd sɛn səm bæk."

"Then perhaps," Egwene said, "it would be best if the Sea Folk sent some of their apprentices to train with you Wise Ones - and perhaps you could send some back."

"tə lɪv ɑn ʃɪps?" məleɪn sɛd, əɡæst.

"To live on ships?" Melaine said, aghast.

"wʌt bɛɾɝ weɪ tə kɑŋkɝ jəɹ fɪɹz ə ðə wɔɾɝ?"

"What better way to conquer your fears of the water?"

"wi ɑɹən əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt" æmɪz snæpt. "wi ɹɪspɛkt ɪt. jə wɛtlələnd-ɝz . . ." ʃi ɔlweɪz spoʊk ə ʃɪps əz wʌn spoʊk ʌv ə keɪdʒ laɪən.

"We aren't afraid of it" Amys snapped. "We respect it. You wetlaland-ers . . ." She always spoke of ships as one spoke of a caged lion.

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs." ɛɡwin tɝn bæk tə ðə si foʊk. "ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil kəd bi jʊɹz, ʃəd wɪv ə bɑɹɡən."

"Regardless." Egwene turned back to the Sea Folk. "The ter'angreal could be yours, should we have a bargain."

"ju ɔlɹɛɾi ɡeɪv ðiz tə ʌs," ʃilɪn sɛd.

"You already gave these to us," Shielyn said.

"ðeɪ wɝ lɛn tə ju, ʃilɪn, əz wɑz meɪd vɛɹi klɪɹ baɪ ðə wɪmən u dɪlɪvɝd ðɛm."

"They were lent to you, Shielyn, as was made very clear by the women who delivered them."

"æn jə wəd ɡɪv əm tə əs pɝmənənli?" ʃilɪn æskt. "wɪð nʌn ə ðɪs nɑnsɛns əbaʊɾ ɔl tɛɹæŋɡɹil bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ?"

"And you would give them to us permanently?" Shielyn asked. "With none of this nonsense about all ter'angreal belonging to the White Tower?"

"ɪɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðət ðəɹ bi ə ɹul tə pɹɪvɛn tɛɹæŋɡɹil fɹəm biɪŋ kɛp baɪ ðoʊz u dɪskʌvɝ ðɛm," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðæt weɪ, wi kən ɹimuv ə pətɛnʃəli deɪnʒɝəs aɪɾəm fɹəm ə fulɪʃ mɝtʃən əɹ fɑɹmɝ. bʌɾ aɪ wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə meɪk ə fɔɹməl ɪksɛpʃən fəɹ ðə wɪndndɝz ən waɪz wʌnz."

"It is important that there be a rule to prevent ter'angreal from being kept by those who discover them," Egwene said. "That way, we can remove a potentially dangerous item from a foolish merchant or farmer. But I would be willing to make a formal exception for the Windnnders and Wise Ones."

"soʊ ðə ɡlæs pɪlɝz . . ." æmɪz sɛd. "aɪ hæv wʌndɝɾ ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ ɛvɝ tʃɹaɪ tə leɪ kleɪm tə ðɛm."

"So the glass pillars . . ." Amys said. "I have wondered if the Aes Sedai would ever try to lay claim to them."

"aɪ daʊt ðət wəd hæpən," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ ɔlsoʊ səspɛk ðəɾ ɪt wəɾ iz il maɪnz ɪf wi wɝ tə pɹoʊkleɪm ɪɾ əfɪʃəli, ðət ðoʊz tɛɹæŋɡɹil - ən ʌðɝz jə pəzɛs - bɪlɔŋ tə ju, ən ðət sɪstɝz kænɑt kleɪm ðɛm."

"I doubt that would happen," Egwene said. "But I also suspect that it would ease Aiel minds if we were to proclaim it officially, that those ter'angreal - and others you possess - belong to you, and that sisters cannot claim them."

ðət ɡeɪv ðə waɪz wʌnz sɪɹiəs θɔt.

That gave the Wise Ones serious thought.

"wʌn stɪl faɪn ðɪs əɡɹimən ɑd," bɛɹ sɛd. "il, tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt nɑt bɪkʌmɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪts nɑt ðə weɪ θɪŋz əv bɪn."

"1 still find this agreement odd," Bair said. "Aiel, training in the White Tower, but not becoming Aes Sedai? It is not the way things have been."

"ðə wɝld ɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, bɛɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli. "bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, ðəɹ wɑz ə pætʃ ə faɪn, kʌltəveɪɾəd ɛmənz ɡlɔɹi flaʊɝz nɪɹ ə bɹʊk. maɪ fɑðɝ laɪk tə wɔk ðɛɹ, ən lʌv ðɛɹ bjuɾi. bʌt ðən wən ðə nu bɹɪdʒ wɑz bɪlt, pipəl bɪɡæn tʃɹeɪpsɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə pætʃ tə ɡɛt tə ɪt.

"The world is changing, Bair," Egwene said softly. "Back in Emond's Field, there was a patch of fine, cultivated Emond's Glory flowers near a brook. My father liked to walk there, and loved their beauty. But then when the new bridge was built, people began traipsing across the patch to get to it.

"maɪ fɑðɝ tʃɹaɪd fəɹ jɪɹz tə kip əm ɔf ðə pætʃ. smɔl fɛnsəz, saɪnz. nʌθɪŋ wɝkt. ən ðən i θɔt tə bɪld ə nit pæθ ə ɹɪvɝ stoʊnz θɹu ðə pætʃ, kʌltɪveɪɾɪŋ ðə flaʊɝz tə ðə saɪdz. æftɝ ðæt, pipəl stɑpt wɔkɪŋ ɑn ðɛm.

"My father tried for years to keep them off the patch. Small fences, signs. Nothing worked. And then he thought to build a neat path of river stones through the patch, cultivating the flowers to the sides. After that, people stopped walking on them.

"wɛn tʃeɪnʒ kʌmz, jə kən skɹim ən tʃɹaɪ tə fɔɹs θɪŋz tə steɪ ðə seɪm. bʌt jəl juʒəwəli ɛn ʌp ɡɛɾɪŋ tʃɹæmpəld. haʊɛvɝ, ɪf jə kən dɝɛk ðə tʃeɪnʒəz, ðeɪ kən sɝv ju. dʒʌst əz ðə paʊɝ sɝvz ʌs, bʌɾ oʊnli æftɝ wi sɝɛndɝ tə ɪt."

"When change comes, you can scream and try to force things to stay the same. But you'll usually end up getting trampled. However, if you can direct the changes, they can serve you. Just as the Power serves us, but only after we surrender to it."

ɛɡwin lʊkt əɾ itʃ wʊmən ɪn tɝn. "aʊɝ θɹi ɡɹups ʃʊɾə bɪɡʌn wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz əpɑn ʌs, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn θɹɛɾənz tə fɹi ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪf ðət wɝn ɪnʌf, wɪv ənʌðɝ kɑmən foʊ - wʌn u wəd si ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪndndɝz ən waɪz wʌnz əlaɪk dɪstʃɹɔɪd."

Egwene looked at each woman in turn. "Our three groups should have begun working together long ago. The Last Battle is upon us, and the Dragon Reborn threatens to free the Dark One. If that weren't enough, we have another common foe - one who would see Aes Sedai, Windnnders and Wise Ones alike destroyed."

"ðə sintʃæn," məleɪn sɛd.

"The Seanchan," Melaine said.

ɹɪneɪl, sɪɾɪŋ ət ðə bæk ə ðə wɪndndɝz, lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɑf hɪs ət ðə wɝd. hɝ kloʊðɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd, ən ʃi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ɑɹmɝ, hoʊldɪŋ ə sɔɹd. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ə moʊmənt.

Renaile, sitting at the back of the Windnnders, let out a soft hiss at the word. Her clothing changed, and she was wearing armor, holding a sword. It was gone in a moment.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "təɡɛðɝ, wi kən bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə faɪɾ əm əpɑɹt. . ."

"Yes," Egwene said. "Together, we can be strong enough to fight them Apart. . ."

"wi mʌs kənsɪɾɝ ðɪs bɑɹɡən," ʃilɪn sɛd. ɛɡwin noʊɾəst ə wɪn bloʊɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹum, laɪkli kɹieɪɾəd baɪ wʌn ə ðə si foʊk baɪ æksəɾənt. "wi wɪl miɾ əɡɛn ən pɝhæps meɪk ə pɹɑməs.

"We must consider this bargain," Shielyn said. Egwene noticed a wind blowing through the room, likely created by one of the Sea Folk by accident. "We will meet again and perhaps make a promise.

ɪf wi meɪk ɪt, ðə tɝmz wɪl bi ðɪs: wɪl sɛn jə tu əpɹɛntəsɪz ə jɪɹ, ən jəl sɛn tu tə ʌs."

If we make it, the terms will be this: We will send you two apprentices a year, and you will send two to us."

"nɑt jəɹ wikəst," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ wɑn jəɹ moʊs pɹɑməsɪŋ."

"Not your weakest," Egwene said. "I want your most promising."

"æn jəl sɛn ðə seɪm?" ʃilɪn sɛd.

"And you will send the same?" Shielyn said.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. tu wɑz ə stɑɹt. ðeɪ wəd pɹɑbli wɪʃ tə muv tə lɑɹdʒɝ nʌmbɝz wʌns ðə plæn wɑz pɹuvən ɪfɛktɪv. bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt pʊʃ fəɹ ðəɾ ət ðə stɑɹt.

"Yes," Egwene said. Two was a start. They would probably wish to move to larger numbers once the plan was proven effective. But she would not push for that at the start.

"æn ʌs?" æmɪz sɛd. "wi ɑɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs 'bɑɹɡən' əz jə pʊɾ ɪt?"

"And us?" Amys said. "We are part of this 'bargain' as you put it?"

"tu æksɛptɪd," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ tu əpɹɛntəsɪz. ðeɪ tʃɹeɪn fəɹ ə pɪɹiəɾ ə noʊ lɛs ðən sɪks mʌnθs, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu jɪɹz. wʌns əɹ wɪmən ɑɹ əmʌŋ ju, ðeɪ ɑɹ tə bi kənsɪɾɝd jəɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz, ən mʌs fɑloʊ jəɹ ɹulz." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "æt ði ɛn ə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ɔl əpɹɛntəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ pipəl fəɹ ət list wʌn jɪɹ. æftɝ ðæt, ɪf jʊɹz dɪsaɪd ðeɪ wɑnə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðeɪ kən ɹɪtɝn tə bi kənsɪɾɝd. ðə seɪm ɡoʊz fəɹ wɪmən əmʌŋ ʌs, ʃəd ðeɪ dɪsaɪd tə dʒɔɪn wɪð jə ɪnstɛd."

"Two Accepted," Egwene said, "in return for two apprentices. They train for a period of no less than six months, but no more than two years. Once our women are among you, they are to be considered your apprentices, and must follow your rules." She hesitated. "At the end of their training, all apprentices and Accepted must return to their people for at least one year. After that, if yours decide they want to be Aes Sedai, they can return to be considered. The same goes for women among us, should they decide to join with you instead."

bɛɹ nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. "pɝhæps ðəɹ wɪl bi wɪmən laɪk jɝsɛlf hu, siɪŋ əɹ weɪz, wɪl noʊ ðɛm supɪɹiɝ. ɪts stɪl ə ʃeɪm wi lɔs ju."

Bair nodded thoughtfully. "Perhaps there will be women like yourself who, seeing our ways, will know them superior. It is still a shame we lost you."

"maɪ pleɪs wɑz ɛlswɛɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"My place was elsewhere," Egwene said.

"wɪl jə æksɛp ðɪs bɪtwin əs əz wɛl?" ʃilɪn sɛd tə ðə waɪz wʌnz. "ʃʊd wi əɡɹi tə ðɪs bɑɹɡən, tu fəɹ tu, ɪn ə sɪməlɝ mænɝ?

"Will you accept this between us as well?" Shielyn said to the Wise Ones. "Should we agree to this bargain, two for two, in a similar manner?

"ɪf ðə bɑɹɡən ɪz əɡɹid tə," bɛɹ sɛd, lʊkɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz, "wi wɪl meɪk ɪt wɪð jə əz wɛl. bʌt wi mʌst spik wɪð ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"If the bargain is agreed to," Bair said, looking to the other Wise Ones, "we will make it with you as well. But we must speak with the other Wise Ones about it."

"ænd wʌɾ ə ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹɛəlt ʃilɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ɛɡwin.

"And what of the ter'angrealT Shielyn said, turning back to Egwene.

"jʊɹz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, jəl ɹilis əs fɹəm aʊt pɹɑməs tə sɛn sɪstɝz tə tʃɹeɪn ju, ən wɪl lɛɾ ɛni si foʊk kɝənli əmʌŋ əs ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ pipəl. ɔl ə ðɪs ɪz sʌbʒɪkt tə ði əpɹuvəl ə jəɹ pipəl, ən əl əv tə bɹɪŋ ðɪs bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ."

"Yours," Egwene said. "In exchange, you will release us from out promise to send sisters to train you, and we will let any Sea Folk currently among us return to their people. All of this is subject to the approval of your people, and I will have to bring this before the Hall of the Tower."

ʌv kɔɹs, əz æmɪɝlɪn, hɝ dɪkɹiz wɝ lɔ. ɪf ðə hɔl bɔkt, haʊɛvɝ, ðoʊz lɔz kəɾ ɛn ʌp biɪŋ ɪɡnɔɹd. ɪn ðɪs, ʃi wəd nid tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ səpɔɹt - ən ʃi wɑntəd tə, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli kənsɪɾɝɪŋ əɹ stæns ðət ðə hɔl ʃəd wɝk təɡɛðɝ wɪð əɹ mɔɹ ən miɾ ɪn sikɹət lɛs.

Of course, as Amyrlin, her decrees were law. If the Hall balked, however, those laws could end up being ignored. In this, she would need to get their support - and she wanted to, particularly considering her stance that the Hall should work together with her more and meet in secret less.

ʃi wɑz ɹizənəbli sɝɾən ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ əpɹuvəl fəɹ ðɪs pɹəpoʊzəl, haʊɛvɝ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊdn laɪk ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp tɛɹæŋɡɹil, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ dɪd nɑt laɪk ðə bɑɹɡən ðət hæd bɪn meɪd wɪð ðə si foʊk oʊvɝ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz. tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðæt, ðeɪ wəd ɡɪv ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ.

She was reasonably certain she could get approval for this proposal, however. The Aes Sedai wouldn't like giving up ter'angreal, but they also did not like the bargain that had been made with the Sea Folk over the Bowl of the Winds. To be rid of that, they would give almost anything.

"aɪ nu jə wəd tʃɹaɪ tə ɛn ðə sɪstɝz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ʌs," ʃilɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd.

"I knew you would try to end the sisters training us," Shielyn said, sounding self-satisfied.

"wɪtʃ wəd jə ɹæðɝ hæv?" ɛɡwin æskt. "wɪmən u ɑɹ əmʌŋ əɹ wikəs mɛmbɝz, ən u si ðɛɹ sɝvəs əz ə pʌnɪʃmənt? əɹ ɪnstɛd, jəɹ oʊn si foʊk, hu hæv lɝn ðə bɛst wi kən ɔfɝ ən ɹɪtɝn hæpəli tə ʃɛɹ?" ɛɡwin hæd bɪn hæf-tɛmptəd tə sɪmpli sɛn si foʊk ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ðɛm tə fʊlfɪl ðə bɑɹɡən ɛniweɪ; ɪt simd ə pɹɑpɝ twɪstɪŋ ə ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən.

"Which would you rather have?" Egwene asked. "Women who are among our weakest members, and who see their service as a punishment? Or instead, your own Sea Folk, who have learned the best we can offer and return happily to share?" Egwene had been half-tempted to simply send Sea Folk Aes Sedai to them to fulfill the bargain anyway; it seemed a proper twisting of the situation.

hoʊpfəli, haʊɛvɝ, ðɪs nu bɑɹɡən wəd səplæn ði oʊld wʌn. ʃi hæɾ ə filɪŋ ʃid luz ðə si foʊk sɪstɝz ɛniweɪ, ət lis ðə wʌnz u lɔŋ tə bi bæk wɪð ðɛɹ pipəl. ðə wɝld wɑz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, ən naʊ ðət ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə sikɹət, ði oʊld weɪz nid nɑt bi meɪnteɪnd.

Hopefully, however, this new bargain would supplant the old one. She had a feeling she'd lose the Sea Folk sisters anyway, at least the ones who longed to be back with their people. The world was changing, and now that the Windfinders were no longer a secret, the old ways need not be maintained.

"wi wɪl dɪskʌs," ʃilɪn sɛd. ʃi nɑɾəd tə ði ʌðɝz, ən ðeɪ vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə ɹum. ðeɪ sɝɾənli dɪd lɝn kwɪkli.

"We will discuss," Shielyn said. She nodded to the others, and they vanished from the room. They certainly did learn quickly.

"ðɪs dæns ɪz ə deɪnʒɝəs wʌn, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," æmɪz sɛd, stændɪŋ ən ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl.

"This dance is a dangerous one, Egwene al'Vere," Amys said, standing and adjusting her shawl.

"ðɛɹ wɑz ə taɪm wən ði il wʊɾə teɪkən pɹaɪd tə hæv sɝv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðət taɪm əz pæst."

"There was a time when the Aiel would have taken pride to have served the Aes Sedai. That time has passed."

"ðə wɪmən jə θɔt jə wəd faɪn ɑɹ nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə dʒɹim, æmɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"The women you thought you would find are nothing more than a dream, Amys," Egwene said.

"ɹil laɪf ɪz ɔfən mɔɹ dɪsəpɔɪntɪŋ ðən dʒɹimz, bʌɾ ət list wən jə faɪn ɑnɝ ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, jə noʊ ɪt tə bi mɔɹ ðən ə fænsi."

"Real life is often more disappointing than dreams, but at least when you find honor in the real world, you know it to be more than a fancy."

ðə waɪz wʌn nɑɾəd. "wi wɪl laɪkli əɡɹi tə ðɪs bɑɹɡən. wɪv nid tə lɝn wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kən titʃ."

The Wise One nodded. "We will likely agree to this bargain. We have need to learn what the Aes Sedai can teach."

wɪl pɪk əɹ stʃɹɔŋɡəst wɪmən," bɛɹ æɾəd. "ðoʊz u wɪl nɑt bi kɝʌptɪd baɪ wɛtləndɝ sɔfnəs." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɑndəmneɪʃən ɪn ðoʊz wɝdz. kɔlɪŋ wɛtləndɝz sɑft wɑz nɑɾ ən ɪnsəlt, ɪn bɛɹz maɪnd.

We will pick our strongest women," Bair added. "Those who will not be corrupted by wetlander softness." There was no condemnation in those words. Calling wetlanders soft was not an insult, in Bair's mind.

æmɪz nɑɾəd. "ðɪs wɝk jə də ɪz ə ɡʊd wʌn soʊ lɔŋ əz jə də nɑt pɹɪzum tə taɪ əs ɪn stil bænz."

Amys nodded. "This work you do is a good one so long as you do not presume to tie us in steel bands."

noʊ, æmɪz, ɛɡwin θɔt. əl nɑt taɪ jə ɪn bænz ə stil. əl juz leɪs ɪnstɛd.

No, Amys, Egwene thought. I will not tie you in bands of steel. I'll use lace instead.

naʊ," bɛɹ sɛd. "ju stɪl əv niɾ ʌv əs ðɪs deɪ? jə ɪndəkeɪɾəd ə bæɾəl ...? "

Now," Bair said. "You still have need of us this day? You indicated a battle ...? "

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɔɹ soʊ aɪ hoʊp." noʊ wɝd hæd kʌm. ðət mɛnt nɪneɪiv ən sɪuən hædn dɪskʌvɝɾ ɛniwʌn lɪsnɪŋ. hæɾ əɹ plɔɪ feɪld?

"Yes," Egwene said. "Or so I hope." No word had come. That meant Nynaeve and Siuan hadn't discovered anyone listening. Had her ploy failed?

ðə waɪz wʌnz nɑɾəd tə hɝ, ðən wɔk tə ðə saɪd, kənfɝɪŋ kwaɪətli. ɛɡwin tʃɹeɪld oʊvɝ tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

The Wise Ones nodded to her, then walked to the side, conferring quietly. Egwene trailed over to the Aes Sedai.

jukɪɝi stʊd. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs, mʌðɝ," jukɪɝi sɛd, spikɪŋ sɔfli ən aɪɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə hɔl wɪl əɡɹi tə ðɪs. mɛni ɑɹ æɾəmənt ðəɾ ɔl ɑbʒɛkts ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ʃəd bɪlɔŋ tə ʌs."

Yukiri stood. "I don't like this, Mother," Yukiri said, speaking softly and eyeing the Wise Ones. "I don't think the Hall will agree to this. Many are adamant that all objects of the One Power should belong to us."

"ðə hɔl wɪl si ɹizən," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wiv ɔlɹɛɾi ɹɪtɝn ðə boʊl ʌv wɪnz tə ðə si foʊk, ən naʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪn əz ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd ðə mɛθəɾ ə kɹæftɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ɪts oʊnli ə mæɾɝ ə taɪm bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ soʊ mɛni wi kænɑt kip tʃɹæk ə ðɛm ɔl."

"The Hall will see reason," Egwene said. "We've already returned the Bowl of Winds to the Sea Folk, and now that Elayne has rediscovered the method of crafting ter'angreal, it is only a matter of time before there are so many we cannot keep track of them all."

"bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɪz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, mʌðɝ," sin sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ, feɪs tʃɹʌbəld. "ʃʊɹli jə kən kip əɹ ɪn laɪn."

"But Elayne is an Aes Sedai, Mother," Seaine said, rising, face troubled. "Surely you can keep her in line."

"pɝhæps," ɛɡwin sɛd, spikɪŋ sɔfli. "bʌt dʌzn ɪt stʃɹaɪk jə ɑd ðət - æftɝ ɔl ə ðiz jɪɹz - soʊ mɛni tæləns ɑɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ, soʊ mɛni dɪskʌvɝiz biɪŋ meɪd? maɪ dʒɹimɪŋ, ɪleɪnz tɛɹæŋɡɹil, fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. ɹɛɹ tæləns sim ɪn əbʌndəns. ən eɪdʒ ɪz ɛndɪŋ, ən ðə wɝld ɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. aɪ daʊt ðəɾ ɪleɪnz tælənt wɪl ɹɪmeɪn junik. wʌɾ ɪf wʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz əɹ si foʊk mænəfɛst ɪt?"

"Perhaps," Egwene said, speaking softly. "But doesn't it strike you odd that - after all of these years - so many Talents are returning, so many discoveries being made? My Dreaming, Elayne's ter'angreal, Foretelling. Rare Talents seem in abundance. An Age is ending, and the world is changing. I doubt that Elayne's Talent will remain unique. What if one of the Wise Ones or Sea Folk manifest it?"

ði ʌðɝ θɹi sæt kwaɪətli, tʃɹʌbəld.

The other three sat quietly, troubled.

"ɪt stɪl ɪzən ɹaɪt tə ɡɪv ʌp, mʌðɝ," jukɪɝi faɪnəli sɛd. "wɪð ɛfɝt, wi kəd bɹɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz ən wɪndfɪndɝz ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl."

"It still isn't right to give up, Mother," Yukiri finally said. "With effort, we could bring the Wise Ones and Windfinders under control."

"æn ði æʃəmən?" ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli, əneɪbəl tə kip ə hɪn ə dɪskʌmfɝɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs.

"And the Asha'man?" Egwene said softly, unable to keep a hint of discomfort out of her voice.

"wɪl wi ɪnsɪs ðəɾ ɔl æŋɡɹil ən sɑŋɡɹil kɹieɪɾəd fəɹ mɛn bɪlɔŋ tə ʌs, ðoʊ wi kænɑt juz ðɛm? wʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ æʃəmən u lɝn tə kɹieɪɾ ɑbʒɛkts ə paʊɝ? wɪl wi fɔɹs əm tə ɡɪv ʌp ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ kɹieɪt tə ʌs? kəd wi ɛnfɔɹs ðæt?"

"Will we insist that all angreal and sa'angreal created for men belong to us, though we cannot use them? What if there are Asha'man who learn to create objects of Power? Will we force them to give up everything they create to us? Could we enforce that?"

"aɪ . . ." jukɪɝi sɛd.

"I . . ." Yukiri said.

lin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ʃiz ɹaɪt, jukɪɝi. laɪt, bʌt ʃi ɪz."

Leane shook her head. "She's right, Yukiri. Light, but she is."

"ðə wɝld əz ɪt wɑz kænɑt bi aʊɝz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli, nɑt wɑntɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. "wɑz ɪɾ ɛvɝ? ðə blæk taʊɝ bɑnz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ði il noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɪvɪɹ ʌs, ðə wɪndfɪndɝz əv hɪɾən ðɛɹ bɛs tʃænlɝz fɹəm əs fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz ən ɑɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli bəlɪdʒɝənt. ɪf wi tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊl tu taɪtli tə ɔl ə ðɪs, wɪl iðɝ bɪkʌm taɪɹəns əɹ fulz, dɪpɛndɪŋ əpɑn haʊ səksɛsfəl wi ɑɹ. aɪ æksɛp niðɝ taɪɾəl.

"The world as it was cannot be ours any longer," Egwene said softly, not wanting the Wise Ones to overhear. "Was it ever? The Black Tower bonds Aes Sedai, the Aiel no longer revere us, the Windfinders have hidden their best channelers from us for centuries and are becoming increasingly belligerent. If we try to hold too tightly to all of this, we will either become tyrants or fools, depending upon how successful we are. I accept neither title.

"wi wɪl lid ðɛm, jukɪɝi. wi mʌs bɪkʌm ə sɔɹs ðət wɪmən lʊk tə, ɔl wɪmən. wi ətʃiv ðət baɪ nɑt hoʊldɪŋ tu taɪtli, baɪ bɹɪŋɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃænlɝz tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð əs ən baɪ sɛndɪŋ əɹ moʊs tæləntəɾ æksɛptɪd tə bɪkʌm ɛkspɝts ɪn ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ ɑɹ bɛst æt."

"We will lead them, Yukiri. We must become a source that women look to, all women. We achieve that by not holding too tightly, by bringing their channelers to train with us and by sending our most talented Accepted to become experts in the things they are best at."

"æn ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ seɪɪŋ ðə seɪm θɪŋ ɹaɪt naʊ?" lin æsk sɔfli, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ət ðə waɪz wʌnz, hu wɝ spikɪŋ ɪn hʌʃt toʊnz ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. "ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ tə pleɪ əs əz wi pleɪ ðɛm?"

"And if they are saying the same thing right now?" Leane asked softly, looking over at the Wise Ones, who were speaking in hushed tones on the far side of the room. "If they try to play us as we play them?"

"ðɛn wɪv tə pleɪ ðə bɛst," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɔl ə ðɪs ɪz sɛkəndɛɹi, fəɹ naʊ. wi nid junəɾi əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə sintʃæn. wɪv tə- -  ə fɹæzəld-lʊkɪŋ sɪuən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹum, hɝ dʒɹɛs sɪŋʒd ɑn wʌn saɪd. "mʌðɝ! wi nid ju!"

"Then we have to play the best," Egwene said. "All of this is secondary, for now. We need unity against the Shadow and the Seanchan. We have to- -  A frazzled-looking Siuan appeared in the room, her dress singed on one side. "Mother! We need you!"

"ðə bæɾəl əz bɪɡʌn?" ɛɡwin sɛd, ɝdʒənt. tə ðə saɪd, ðə waɪz wʌnz pɝkt ʌp.

"The battle has begun?" Egwene said, urgent. To the side, the Wise Ones perked up.

"ɪt hæz," sɪuən sɛd, pæntɪŋ. "ɪt hæpən ɹaɪɾ ɔf. mʌðɝ, ðeɪ dɪdn kʌm tə ivzdʒɹɑp! ðeɪ ətækt"

"It has," Siuan said, panting. "It happened right off. Mother, they didn't come to eavesdrop! They attacked"

pɛɹɪn stʃɹikt əkɹɔs ðə lænd, kʌvɝɪŋ liɡz wɪð itʃ stɛp. hi niɾəd tə teɪk ðə spaɪk sʌmpleɪs əweɪ fɹəm sleɪɝ. pɝhæps ði oʊʃən? hi kəd -  ən æɹoʊ hɪs θɹu ði ɛɹ, slaɪsɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. pɛɹɪn kɝst ən spʌn. ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ə haɪ ɹɑki hɪlsaɪd. sleɪɝ stʊd daʊnhɪl fɹəm hɪm, baʊ ɹeɪz tə hɪz æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs, dɑɹk aɪz əlaɪt wɪð æŋɡɝ. hi ɹilist ənʌðɝ æɹoʊ.

Perrin streaked across the land, covering leagues with each step. He needed to take the spike someplace away from Slayer. Perhaps the ocean? He could -  An arrow hissed through the air, slicing his shoulder. Perrin cursed and spun. They were on a high rocky hillside. Slayer stood downhill from him, bow raised to his angular face, dark eyes alight with anger. He released another arrow.

ə wɔl, pɛɹɪn θɔt, sʌmənɪŋ ə wɔl ə bɹɪks ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ði æɹoʊ pʌntʃt sɛvɹəl ɪntʃəz ɪndə ðə bɹɪks, bʌt stɑpt. pɛɹɪn ɪmiɾiətli sɛn hɪmsɛlf əweɪ. hi kʊdnt ɡoʊ fɑɹ, ðoʊ, nɑt waɪl kæɹiɪŋ ðə doʊm.

A wall, Perrin thought, summoning a wall of bricks in front of him. The arrow punched several inches into the bricks, but stopped. Perrin immediately sent himself away. He couldn't go far, though, not while carrying the dome.

pɛɹɪn tʃeɪnʒd soʊ ðəɾ i wɑznt ɡoʊɪŋ stʃɹeɪt nɔɹθ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, bʌt muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ði ist. hi daʊɾɪd ðət wəd θɹoʊ ɔf sleɪɝ - hi kəd pɹɑbli si ðə doʊm muvɪŋ ən dʒʌdʒ ɪts dɝɛkʃən.

Perrin changed so that he wasn't going straight north any longer, but moving toward the east. He doubted that would throw off Slayer - he could probably see the dome moving and judge its direction.

wʌt tə du? hid plæn tə tɔs ðə spaɪk ɪndə ði oʊʃən, bʌɾ ɪf sleɪɝ wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ, hid dʒʌst ɹɪkʌvɝ ɪt. pɛɹɪn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn muvɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz i kʊd, kʌvɝɪŋ liɡz wɪð itʃ hɑɹtbit. kəɾ i aʊtʃɹʌn ɪz foʊ? ðə lændskeɪp pæst ɪm ɪn ə blɝ. maʊntənz, fɔɹəsts, leɪks, mɛdoʊz.

What to do? He'd planned to toss the spike into the ocean, but if Slayer was following, he'd just recover it. Perrin concentrated on moving as quickly as he could, covering leagues with each heartbeat. Could he outrun his foe? The landscape passed him in a blur. Mountains, forests, lakes, meadows.

dʒʌst əz i θɔɾ i maɪɾ əv ɡɑɾən əhɛd, ə fɪɡjɝ əpɪɹd dʒʌs bɪsaɪd hɪm, swɪŋɪŋ ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz nɛk. pɛɹɪn dʌkt, bɛɹli dɑdʒɪŋ ði ətæk. hi ɡɹaʊld, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ, bʌt sleɪɝ vænɪʃt.

Just as he thought he might have gotten ahead, a figure appeared just beside him, swinging a sword at his neck. Perrin ducked, barely dodging the attack. He growled, raising his hammer, but Slayer vanished.

pɛɹɪn stɑpt ɪn pleɪs, fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. sleɪɝ kəd muv fæstɝ ðən pɝ-ɹɪn, ən kəd ɡɛɾ ʌndɝ ðə doʊm baɪ dʒʌmpɪŋ əhɛɾ ʌv ɪt, ðən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə muv ɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə hɪm. fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi kəd dʒʌmp dɝɛkli tə pɝ-ɹɪn ən ətæk.

Perrin stopped in place, frustrated. Slayer could move faster than Per-rin, and could get under the dome by jumping ahead of it, then waiting for Perrin to move it on top of him. From there, he could jump directly to Per-rin and attack.

aɪ kæn aʊtʃɹʌn hɪm, pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd. ði oʊnli weɪ tə bi sɝɾən, ði oʊnli weɪ tə pɹətɛk feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz, wɑz tə kɪl sleɪɝ. ʌðɝwaɪz ðə mæn wəd ɹɪkʌvɝ ðə spaɪk fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ pɛɹɪn pʊɾ ɪt, ðən ɹɪtɝn ɪt tə tʃɹæp ɪz pipəl.

I can't outrun him, Perrin realized. The only way to be certain, the only way to protect Faile and the others, was to kill Slayer. Otherwise the man would recover the spike from wherever Perrin put it, then return it to trap his people.

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ɝaʊnd, ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz bɛɹɪŋz. hi wɑz ɑn ə laɪtli fɔɹ-ɛstəd sloʊp, ən kəd si dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn tə ðə nɔɹθ ə hɪm. hi ɡlænst istwɝd, ən sɔ ðə tɪp ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ stʃɹʌktʃɝ pikɪŋ aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹi-tɑps. ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə sɪɾi maɪt ɡɪv pɛɹɪn ən ædvæntɪdʒ, meɪk ɪɾ iziɝ tə haɪɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə mɛni bɪldɪŋz əɹ æliz.

Perrin glanced around, getting his bearings. He was on a lightly for-ested slope, and could see Dragonmount to the north of him. He glanced eastward, and saw the tip of a large structure peeking out over the tree-tops. The White Tower. The city might give Perrin an advantage, make it easier to hide in one of the many buildings or alleys.

pɛɹɪn lɛpt ɔf ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən, kæɹiɪŋ ðə spaɪk wɪð hɪm, ðə doʊm ɪt kɹieɪɾəd tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ɪm əz i muvd. ɪt wəd kʌm daʊn tə ə faɪɾ æftɝ ɔl.

Perrin leaped off in that direction, carrying the spike with him, the dome it created traveling with him as he moved. It would come down to a fight after all.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 37

dɑɹknəs ɪn ðə taʊɝ


Darkness in the Tower

ɡɔɪn sæɾ ɑn ə bɛntʃ ɪn ðə keɪɛmlɪn pæləs ɡɑɹɾənz. ɪt hæd bɪn sɛvɹəl aʊɝz sɪns hid sɛn ɛɡwinz mɛsənʒɝ əweɪ. ə ɡɪbəs mun hʌŋ fæɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ. sɝvəns əkeɪʒənəli pæs baɪ tə si ɪf i niɾəd ɛniθɪŋ. ðeɪ simd wɝiɾ əbaʊt hɪm.

Gawyn sat on a bench in the Caemlyn Palace gardens. It had been several hours since he'd sent Egwene's messenger away. A gibbous moon hung fat in the sky. Servants occasionally passed by to see if he needed anything. They seemed worried about him.

hi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə wɑtʃ ðə skaɪ. ɪt hæd bɪn wiks sɪns hid bɪn eɪbəl tə də ðæt. ði ɛɹ wɑz kulɪŋ, bʌɾ i lɛft ɪz koʊɾ ɔf, hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə bæk ə ðə bɛntʃ. ði oʊpən ɛɹ fɛlt ɡʊd - dɪfɹənt, sʌmhaʊ, fɹəm ðə seɪm ɛɹ bɪniθ ə klaʊɾi skaɪ.

He just wanted to watch the sky. It had been weeks since he'd been able to do that. The air was cooling, but he left his coat off, hung over the back of the bench. The open air felt good - different, somehow, from the same air beneath a cloudy sky.

wɪð ðə læs laɪɾ ə dʌsk feɪɾɪŋ, ðə stɑɹz ʃoʊn laɪk hɛzɪɾənt tʃɪlʒɹən, pikɪŋ aʊt naʊ ðət ði ʌpɹɔɹ ə deɪ hæd daɪd daʊn. ɪt fɛl soʊ ɡʊd tə faɪnəli si ðɛm əɡɛn. ɡɔɪn bɹiðd ɪn dipli.

With the last light of dusk fading, the stars shone like hesitant children, peeking out now that the uproar of day had died down. It felt so good to finally see them again. Gawyn breathed in deeply.

ɪleɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. mʌtʃ ʌv ɡɔɪnz heɪtʃɹəɾ ʌv ælθɹ keɪm fɹəm fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. meɪbi dʒɛləsi.

Elayne was right. Much of Gawyn's hatred of al'Thor came from frustration. Maybe jealousy.

ælθɹ wɑz pleɪɪŋ ə ɹoʊl kloʊsɝ tə wʌt ɡɔɪn wʊɾə tʃoʊzən fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. ɹulɪŋ neɪʃənz, liɾɪŋ ɑɹmiz. lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛɹ laɪvz, hu hæd teɪkən ɑn ðə ɹoʊl ʌv ə pɹɪns, ən u ðə ɹoʊl ʌv ə lɔst ʃifɝɾɝ?

Al'Thor was playing a role closer to what Gawyn would have chosen for himself. Ruling nations, leading armies. Looking at their lives, who had taken on the role of a prince, and who the role of a lost sheepherder?

pɝhæps ɡɔɪn ɹɪzɪstɪɾ ɛɡwinz dɪmænz kəz i wɑntəd tə lid, tə bi ðə wʌn u əkɑmplɪʃt ðə hɪɹoʊɪk æks. ɪf i bɪkeɪm əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, hi wəɾ əv tə stɛp əsaɪɾ ən hɛlp əɹ tʃeɪnʒ ðə wɝld. ðəɹ wɑz ɑnɝ ɪn kipɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɡɹeɪɾ əlaɪv. ə dip ɑnɝ. wʌt wɑz ðə pɔɪn ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ æks? ðə ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən ðeɪ bɹɔt, əɹ ðə bɛɾɝ laɪvz ðeɪ kɹieɪɾəd?

Perhaps Gawyn resisted Egwene's demands because he wanted to lead, to be the one who accomplished the heroic acts. If he became her Warder, he would have to step aside and help her change the world. There was honor in keeping someone great alive. A deep honor. What was the point of great acts? The recognition they brought, or the better lives they created?

tə stɛp əsaɪd. hiɾ ədmaɪɝd mɛn laɪk slit fəɹ ðɛɹ wɪlɪŋnəs tə də ðɪs, bʌt hæd nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd ðɛm. nɑt tʃɹuli. / kæn liv əɹ tə də ɪɾ əloʊn, hi θɔt. sɛvən əv tə hɛlp hɝ. fɹəm wɪðɪn əɹ ʃædoʊ.

To step aside. He'd admired men like Sleete for their willingness to do this, but had never understood them. Not truly. / can't leave her to do it alone, he thought. 7 have to help her. From within her shadow.

kəz i lʌv hɝ. bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ kəz ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə bɛst. ɪf tu bɑɹdz tʃɹaɪd tə pleɪ dɪfɹən sɔŋz ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ðeɪ boʊθ meɪd nɔɪz. bʌɾ ɪf wʌn stɛp bæk tə ɡɪv hɑɹməni tə ði ʌðɝz mɛləɾi, ðən ðə bjuɾi kəd bi ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən iðɝ meɪɾ əloʊn.

Because he loved her. But also because it was for the best. If two bards tried to play different songs at the same time, they both made noise. But if one stepped back to give harmony to the other's melody, then the beauty could be greater than either made alone.

ən ɪn ðət moʊmənt, faɪnəli, hi ʌndɝstʊd. hi stʊɾ ʌp. hi kʊdnt ɡoʊ tə ɛɡwin əz ə pɹɪns.

And in that moment, finally, he understood. He stood up. He couldn't go to Egwene as a prince.

hi hæd tə ɡoʊ tə hɝ əz ə wɔɹɾɝ. hi hæd tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ hɝ, tə sɝv hɝ. si hɝ wɪʃɪz dʌn.

He had to go to her as a Warder. He had to watch over her, to serve her. See her wishes done.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɹɪtɝn.

It was time to return.

slɪŋɪŋ ɪz koʊɾ ɑn, hi stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə pæθ təwɔɹd ðə pæləs. ði oʊpənɪŋ sɛɹəneɪdz ə vɛɹiəs pɑn fɹɑɡz kʌt ʃɔɹt - fɑloʊd baɪ splæʃəz - əz i pæst əm ən ɛntɝd ðə bɪldɪŋ. ɪt wɑzn ə lɔŋ wɔk tə hɪz sɪstɝz ɹumz. ʃi wəd bi ʌp; ʃi hæd tʃɹʌbəl slipɪŋ leɪtli. dʊɹɪŋ ðə pæs fju deɪz, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔfən ɛndʒɔɪd kɑnvɝseɪʃən ən ə kʌp ʌv wɔɹm ti bɪfɔɹ bɛd. əɾ əɹ dɔɹz, haʊɛvɝ, hi wɑz stɑp baɪ bɝdʒɪt.

Slinging his coat on, he strode down the path toward the Palace. The opening serenades of various pond frogs cut short - followed by splashes - as he passed them and entered the building. It wasn't a long walk to his sister's rooms. She would be up; she had trouble sleeping lately. During the past few days, they had often enjoyed conversation and a cup of warm tea before bed. At her doors, however, he was stopped by Birgitte.

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ənʌðɝ ɡlɛɹ. jɛs, ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ækt əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ɪn ɪz stɛd. hi kəd si ðət naʊ. hi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl ɑkwɝd stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə hɝ. ðə wʊmən hɛld ʌp ə hænd.

She gave him another glare. Yes, she did not like being forced to act as Captain-General in his stead. He could see that now. He felt a little awkward stepping up to her. The woman held up a hand.

"nɑt tənaɪt, pɹɪnsəlɪŋ."

"Not tonight, princeling."

"aɪm livɪŋ fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ," hi sɛd. "aɪd laɪk tə seɪ fɛɹwɛl."

"I'm leaving for the White Tower," he said. "I'd like to say farewell."

hi muv tə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, bʌt bɝdʒɪt hɛld ə hæn əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst, dʒɛnli pʊʃɪŋ ɪm bæk.

He moved to step forward, but Birgitte held a hand against his chest, gently pushing him back.

"ju kən liv ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

"You can leave in the morning."

hi ɔlmoʊst ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd, bʌt stɑp hɪmsɛlf. laɪt! ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə taɪm wən i hædn ɹiæktəd ðət weɪ tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ. hi hæd bɪkʌm ə ful. "æsk ɪf ʃɪl si mi," hi sɛd pəlaɪtli.

He almost reached for his sword, but stopped himself. Light! There had been a time when he hadn't reacted that way to everything. He had become a fool. "Ask if she'll see me," he said politely.

"pliz."

"Please."

ɡɔɪn fɹaʊnd. haʊ wəd . . .

ðə dʒɹimz, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðɪs ɪz wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ mɛnt, əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əm tə wɔk ɪn ðɛɹ dʒɹimz. "soʊ ɛɡwinz slipɪŋ əz wɛl?"

The dreams, he realized. This is what the Aes Sedai meant, about Egwene training them to walk in their dreams. "So Egwene's sleeping as well?"

bɝdʒɪɾ aɪd hɪm. "blʌɾi æʃəz, aɪv pɹɑbli sɛd tu mʌtʃ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɔf tə jəɹ ɹumz."

Birgitte eyed him. "Bloody ashes, I've probably said too much already. Off to your rooms."

ɡɔɪn stɛpt əweɪ, bʌt nɑt tə ɡoʊ tə hɪz ɹumz. hɪl weɪt fəɹ ə taɪm ʌv wiknəs, hi θɔt, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə sʌldəmz wɝdz. ən wən i stʃɹaɪks, hɪl liv sətʃ dɛsəleɪʃən əz jə wʊdn bɪliv ə sɪŋɡəl mæn kəd kɹieɪt . . .

Gawyn stepped away, but not to go to his rooms. He'll wait for a time of weakness, he thought, remembering the sul'dam's words. And when he strikes, he'll leave such desolation as you wouldn't believe a single man could create . . .

ə taɪm ʌv wiknəs.

A time of weakness.

hi dæʃt əweɪ fɹəm ɪleɪnz ɹumz, spɹɪntɪŋ θɹu ðə pæləs hɔlweɪz tə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɹum ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd sɛɾ ʌp. blɛsədli, ə kɪnswʊmən wɑz ɑn duɾi hɪɹ - blɪɹi-aɪd, bʌt weɪɾɪŋ ɪn keɪs ɪmɝdʒənsi mɛsədʒəz niɾəd tə bi sɛnt. ɡɔɪn dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən, bʌt ʃi sim tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm.

He dashed away from Elayne's rooms, sprinting through the palace hallways to the Traveling room that Elayne had set up. Blessedly, a Kinswoman was on duty here - bleary-eyed, but waiting in case emergency messages needed to be sent. Gawyn didn't recognize the dark-haired woman, but she seemed to recognize him.

ʃi jɔn ən oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ əɾ ɪz ɹɪkwɛst. hi ɹæn θɹu ən ɑntu ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊn ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃt ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm. ɡɔɪn stɑɹɾəd, spɪnɪŋ wɪð ə kɝs. ðət hæd nɪɹli kloʊzd ɹaɪɾ ɑn hɪm! waɪ hæd ðə kɪnswʊmən lɛɾ ɪt vænɪʃ soʊ əbɹʌpli, ən soʊ deɪnʒɝəsli? ə splɪt sɛkən sunɝ, ən ɪt wʊɾə teɪkən ɪz fʊɾ ɔf əɹ wɝs.

She yawned and opened a gateway at his request. He ran through and onto the Traveling ground of the White Tower. The gateway vanished right behind him. Gawyn started, spinning with a curse. That had nearly closed right on him! Why had the Kinswoman let it vanish so abruptly, and so dangerously? A split second sooner, and it would have taken his foot off or worse.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm. hi tɝn ən kəntɪnjud ɹʌnɪŋ.

Amys did something that made her form fade away. The rest of you," Egwene said, "go someplace safe. Away from the city." Very well, Mother," Saerin said. She stayed in place, however. What?"

The Wise Ones nodded, and Egwene sent herself there. A lamp sat on her nightstand; it didn't burn here in Tel'aran'rhiod, though she'd left it burning in the real world. The Wise Ones and Leane appeared around her. The gauze draping Egwene s bed ruffled in the breeze of their appearance.

ðə taʊɝ ʃʊk. ðə faɪɾɪŋ kəntɪnjud.

jə nid mi."

You need me."

ðə fɔɹ wɪmən wɪŋkt əweɪ. waɪ kʊdn ðeɪ liv ðə taʊɝ? ɪt wɑz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ jusfəl. ɪt wəd min ʃi wɑz tʃɹæp hɪɹ.

The four women winked away. Why couldn't they leave the Tower? It was troubling, but also useful. It would mean she was trapped here.

bʌt hoʊpfəli soʊ wɑz mɛsænə.

Five doves rose into the air, scattering from the ledge of the rooftop. Perrin spun. Slayer stood behind him, smelling like stone.

Behind him spread a magnificent city. Perrin hadn't believed that any city could be as magnificent as Caemlyn. But if there was such a thing, Tar Valon was it. The entire city was a work of art, almost every building decked with archways, spires, engravings and ornamentation. Even the cobblestones seemed to be arranged artistically.

sleɪɝz aɪz flɪkɝd daʊn tə pɛɹɪnz bɛlt. ðɛɹ, əfɪkst ɪn ə paʊtʃ pɛɹɪn hæd kɹieɪɾəd tə hoʊld ɪt, wɑz ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ðə tɪp stʌk aʊt ðə tɑp, sɪlvɝi bɪts ɹæpɪŋ ɝaʊnd wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ə kɑmplɛks nɑɾɪd bɹeɪd. pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə θɪŋ baɪ θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt, bʌt hæd bɪn ɹɪbʌft. ətækɪŋ ɪt wɪð ɪz hæmɝ hædn soʊ mʌtʃ əz bɛn ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ ðɪs θɪŋ wɑz, ɪt hæd bɪn bɪl tə ɹɪzɪst sətʃ ətæks.

Slayer's eyes flickered down to Perrin's belt. There, affixed in a pouch Perrin had created to hold it, was the ter'angreal. The tip stuck out the top, silvery bits wrapping around one another in a complex knotted braid. Perrin had tried again to destroy the thing by thinking of it, but had been rebuffed. Attacking it with his hammer hadn't so much as bent it. Whatever this thing was, it had been built to resist such attacks.

"juv ɡɹoʊn skɪldwʌn' sleɪɝ sɛd. "aɪ ʃʊɾə kɪl jə mʌnθs əɡoʊ."

"You've grown skilled,1' Slayer said. "I should have killed you months ago."

"ə mæn ə tu wɝlz, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. ən wʌn oʊn baɪ boʊθ. əl nid ðə dʒɹimspaɪk bæk."

"A man of two worlds, Perrin Aybara. And one owned by both. I'll need the dreamspike back."

"stɛp kloʊsɝ, ən əl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd.
