sleɪɝ snɔɹɾɪd, wɔkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. "ju doʊn əv ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ fəɹ ðæt, bɔɪ. aɪ doʊn ivən əv ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə mænədʒ ðæt." hɪz aɪz flɪkɝɾ ʌnkɑnʃəsli oʊvɝ pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. təwɔɹd wʌt?

Slayer snorted, walking forward. "You don't have the strength for that, boy. I don't even have the strength to manage that." His eyes flickered unconsciously over Perrin's shoulder. Toward what?

dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hi mʌst əv wɝiɾ aɪ wɑz kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ tə tɔs ɪɾ ɪn. wɑz ðæt, ðɛn, ən ɪndəkeɪʃən ʌv ə weɪ pɛɹɪn kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil? əɹ wɑz sleɪɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə mɪslid hɪm?

Dragonmount, Perrin thought. He must have worried I was coming this way to toss it in. Was that, then, an indication of a way Perrin could destroy the ter'angreal? Or was Slayer trying to mislead him?

"doʊn pɹɛs mi, bɔɪ," sleɪɝ sɛd, sɔɹɾ ən naɪf əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænz əz i wɔk fɔɹwɝd.

"Don't press me, boy," Slayer said, sword and knife appearing in his hands as he walked forward.

"aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi kɪl fɔɹ wʊlvz tədeɪ. ɡɪmi ðə spaɪk."

"I've already killed four wolves today. Give me the spike."

fɔɹ? bʌt hid kɪld oʊnli wʌn ðət pɛɹɪn hæd sin. hiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡoʊd mi.

Four? But he'd killed only one that Perrin had seen. He's trying to goad me.

jə θɪŋk əl bɪliv ðət jə woʊn kɪl mi ɪf aɪ ɡɪv ɪt tə ju?" pɝ- ɹɪn sɛd. "ɪf aɪ ɡeɪv ðɪs tə ju, juɾ əv tə ɡoʊ pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɪn ɡildən.

You think I'll believe that you won't kill me if I give it to you?" Per- rin said. "If I gave this to you, you'd have to go put it back in Ghealdan.

jə noʊ aɪd dʒʌs fɑloʊ jə ðɛɹ." pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wʌn ʌv əs əz tə daɪ, ən ðæts ðæt."

You know I'd just follow you there." Perrin shook his head. "One of us has to die, and that's that."

sleɪɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən smaɪld. "luk heɪts ju, jə noʊ. heɪts jə dipli."

Slayer hesitated, then smiled. "Luc hates you, you know. Hates you deeply."

ən jə doʊnt?" pɛɹɪn æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðə wʊlf heɪts ðə stæɡ."

And you don't?" Perrin asked, frowning. No more than the wolf hates the stag."

"ju ɑɹ nɑɾ ə wʊlf," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ sɔfli.

"You are not a wolf," Perrin said, growling softly.

sleɪɝ ʃɹʌɡd. "lɛɾ əs bi dʌn wɪð ðɪs, ðɛn." hi dæʃt fɔɹwɝd ɡɔɪn tʃɑɹdʒd ɪndə ðə waɪt taʊɝ; ðə mɛn ɑn ɡɑɹd bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə səlut. hi dæʃt pæs mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps. oʊnli wʌn ɪn ɛvɹi tu wɑz lɪt, tə kənsɝv ɔɪl. əz i ɹitʃt ə ɹæmp ʌpwɝd, hi hɝd fit bi-haɪn hɪm.

Slayer shrugged. "Let us be done with this, then." He dashed forward Gawyn charged into the White Tower; the men on guard barely had time to salute. He dashed past mirrored stand-lamps. Only one in every two was lit, to conserve oil. As he reached a ramp upward, he heard feet be-hind him.

hɪz sɔɹd hɪst əz i pʊld ɪt fɹi, spɪnɪŋ. mɑzoʊni ən sɛlɑɹk pʊl tə ə hɔlt. ðə fɔɹmɝ jʌŋɡəlɪŋz wɔɹ taʊɝ ɡɑɹd junəfɔɹmz naʊ wəd ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɪm? hu nu wʌt kaɪndə ɔɹɾɝz ɛɡwin hæd lɛft?

His sword hissed as he pulled it free, spinning. Mazone and Celark pulled to a halt. The former Younglings wore Tower Guard uniforms now Would they try to stop him? Who knew what kind of orders Egwene had left?

ðeɪ səluɾəd.

They saluted.

"mɛn?" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?"

"Men?" Gawyn said. "What are you doing?"

"sɝ," sɛlɑɹk sɛd, lin feɪs ʃæɾoʊd ɪn ðə pætʃi læmplaɪt. "wɛn ən ɔfəsɝ ɹʌnz baɪ wɪð ə lʊk laɪk ðəɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, jə doʊn æsk ɪf i nidz hɛlp. jə dʒʌs fɑloʊ!"

"Sir," Celark said, lean face shadowed in the patchy lamplight. "When an officer runs by with a look like that on his face, you don't ask if he needs help. You just follow!"

ɡɔɪn smaɪld. "kʌm ɑn." hi dæʃt ʌp ðə ɹæmps, ðə tu mɛn fɑloʊɪŋ, sɔɹdz ət ðə ɹɛɾi.

Gawyn smiled. "Come on." He dashed up the ramps, the two men following, swords at the ready.

ɛɡwin ɛs kɔɹɾɝz wɝ səm weɪ ʌp, ən ɡɔɪnz pʌls wɑz ɹeɪsɪŋ -  hɪz bɹiðɪŋ fɔɹst - baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt əɹ lɛvəl. ðeɪ hɝid daʊn θɹi hɔlweɪz; ðən ɡɔɪn hɛld ʌp ɪz hænd. hi ɡlænst ət ðə nɪɹbaɪ ʃæɾoʊd ɹisɛsəz. wɝ ɛni ʌv əm dip ɪnʌf tə haɪɾ ə blʌd-naɪf?

Egwene s quarters were some way up, and Gawyn's pulse was racing -  his breathing forced - by the time they reached her level. They hurried down three hallways; then Gawyn held up his hand. He glanced at the nearby shadowed recesses. Were any of them deep enough to hide a Blood-knife?

jə kænɑɾ əv laɪt wɪθaʊt ʃædoʊ . . .

You cannot have light without shadow . . .

hi pikt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwinz dɔɹ; hi stʊɾ ɪn vɝtʃuəli ðə seɪm pəzɪʃən i bɪn wən i hæd ɹuən əɹ plænz bɪfɔɹ. wɑz i duɪŋ ðə seɪm θɪŋ naʊ? hɪz tu ɡɑɹdzmɪn stʊɾ ʌp kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz kəmænd.

He peeked around the corner toward Egwene's door; he stood in virtually the same position he been when he had ruined her plans before. Was he doing the same thing now? His two guardsmen stood up close behind him, waiting on his command.

jɛs. hi wɑz duɪŋ ðə seɪm θɪŋ əz bɪfɔɹ. ən jɛt, sʌmθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd. hi wəd si hɝ pɹətɛktəd soʊ ðət ʃi kəd də ɡɹeɪt θɪŋz. hi wəd stæn ɪn əɹ ʃædoʊ ən bi pɹaʊd. hi wəd də əz ʃi æskt - -bʌt wəd si hɝ seɪf noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt.

Yes. He was doing the same thing as before. And yet, something had changed. He would see her protected so that she could do great things. He would stand in her shadow and be proud. He would do as she asked - -but would see her safe no matter what.

kəz ðət wɑz wʌɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ dɪd.

Because that was what a Warder did.

hi slɪp fɔɹwɝd, weɪvɪŋ ɪz mɛn tə fɑloʊ. ðə dɑɹknəs ɪn ðət ʃæɾoʊi ælkoʊv fɹəm bɪfɔɹ dɪdn sim tə ɹɪpɛl ɪz ətɛnʃən əz ɪt hæd læs taɪm. ə ɡʊd saɪn. hi stɑpt ət ðə dɔɹ ən tʃɹaɪɾ ɪt kɛɹfəli. ɪt wɑz ənlɑkt. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən slɪpt ɪnsaɪd.

He slipped forward, waving his men to follow. The darkness in that shadowy alcove from before didn't seem to repel his attention as it had last time. A good sign. He stopped at the door and tried it carefully. It was unlocked. He took a deep breath, then slipped inside.

noʊ əlɑɹmz wɛn ɔf; noʊ tʃɹæps kɑɾ ɪm ən flʌŋ ɪm əbaʊt. ə fju læmps ʃoʊn ɑn ðə wɔlz. əɾ ə feɪnt nɔɪz, hi lʊkt ʌpwɝd. eɪ taʊɝ meɪd hʌŋ ðɛɹ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ, wɪð waɪɾ aɪz, maʊθ ɡæɡd baɪ ən ɪnvɪzəbəl floʊ ʌv ɛɹ.

No alarms went off; no traps caught him and flung him about. A few lamps shone on the walls. At a faint noise, he looked upward. A Tower maid hung there, struggling, with wide eyes, mouth gagged by an invisible flow of Air.

ɡɔɪn kɝst, dæʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, ən θɹu oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə ɛɡwinz slipɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ. hɝ bɛd, wʌn saɪɾ əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ wɔl, wɑz dʒɹeɪpt wɪð waɪt ɡɔz kɝɾənz, ən ə læmp bɝn ɑn ðə stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪt. ɡɔɪn kɹɔs ðə ɹum tə hɝ, pʊʃɪŋ ðə ɡɔz əsaɪd. wɑz ʃi slipɪŋ? əɹ wɑz ʃi...

Gawyn cursed, dashing across the room, and threw open the door to Egwene's sleeping chamber. Her bed, one side against the far wall, was draped with white gauze curtains, and a lamp burned on the stand beside it. Gawyn crossed the room to her, pushing the gauze aside. Was she sleeping? Or was she...

hi ɹitʃt ə hæn təwɔɹɾ əɹ nɛk, bʌɾ əɾ ə feɪn θʌmp bɪhaɪnd, ɡɔɪn wɪpt ɪz sɔɹɾ ɝaʊn ən blɑk ðə stʃɹaɪk kʌmɪŋ əɾ ɪz bæk. nɑt wʌn, bʌt tu blɝz ə dɑɹknəs lɛp fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz. hi spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns fəɹ ɛɡwin; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ blʌd, bʌɾ i kʊdn tɛl ɪf ʃi wɑz bɹiðɪŋ əɹ nɑt. hæɾ ɪz ɛntʃɹəns ɪntɝʌptɪd ði əsæsənz ɪn taɪm?

He reached a hand toward her neck, but at a faint thump behind, Gawyn whipped his sword around and blocked the strike coming at his back. Not one, but two blurs of darkness leaped from the shadows. He spared a glance for Egwene; there was no blood, but he couldn't tell if she was breathing or not. Had his entrance interrupted the assassins in time?

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə tʃɛk. hi fɛl ɪndə æpəl blɑsəmz ɪn ðə wɪn ən bɪɡæn tə ʃaʊt. hɪz mɛn stɛpt ʌp tə ðə dɔɹweɪ, ðən fɹoʊz ðɛɹ, stʌnd.

There was no time to check. He fell into Apple Blossoms in the Wind and began to shout. His men stepped up to the doorway, then froze there, stunned.

"ɡɛt mɔɹ hɛlp!" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ɡoʊ!"

"Get more help!" Gawyn said. "Go!"

dɑɹk-skɪn mɑzoʊni tɝn tə oʊbeɪ waɪl sɛlɑɹk, lʊkɪŋ dɪtɝmənd, lɛpt ɪndə ðə faɪt.

Dark-skinned Mazone turned to obey while Celark, looking determined, leaped into the fight.

ðə blʌdnaɪvz ʃɪftəɾ ən ənʒəleɪtɪd. ɡɔɪn mænədʒ tə slɪp ɪndə kæɾ ɑn hɑt sæn tə tɛs ðɛm, bʌɾ itʃ stʃɹaɪk hɪɾ oʊnli ɛɹ. hɪz aɪz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hɝɾɪŋ fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə fɪɡjɝz.

The Bloodknives shifted and undulated. Gawyn managed to slip into Cat on Hot Sand to test them, but each strike hit only air. His eyes were already hurting from trying to follow the figures.

sɛlɑɹk ətæk fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, bʌt wɑz əz ɪnɪfɛktɪv əz ɡɔɪn. ɡɔɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, faɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɪz bæk əɡɛns ðə bɛd. hi hæd tə kip əm əweɪ fɹəm ɛɡwin, lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ hɛlp tə kʌm.

Celark attacked from behind, but was as ineffective as Gawyn. Gawyn gritted his teeth, fighting with his back against the bed. He had to keep them away from Egwene, long enough for help to come.

ɪf i kəd -  boʊθ fɪɡjɝz twɪstəd sʌɾənli, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ɪn tændəm ət sɛlɑɹk. ðə mæn bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə kɝs bɪfɔɹ ə sɔɹd tʊk ɪm ɪn ðə nɛk, ən bɹaɪt blʌd spɝɾɪd aʊt. ɡɔɪn jɛld əɡɛn, fɔlɪŋ ɪndə lɪzɝɾ ɪn ðə θɔɹnbʊʃ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət ðə bæks ə ði əsæsənz.

If he could -  Both figures twisted suddenly, striking in tandem at Celark. The man barely had time to curse before a sword took him in the neck, and bright blood spurted out. Gawyn yelled again, falling into Lizard in the Thornbush, striking at the backs of the assassins.

əɡɛn, hɪz ətæks mɪst. ɪt simd i wɑz ɔf baɪ oʊnli ə fju hɛɹz. sɛlɑɹk stʌmbəl tə ðə flɔɹ wɪð ə ɡɝɡəl, hɪz blʌd ɹəflɛktɪŋ læntɝnlaɪt, ən ɡɔɪn kʊdn stɛp fɔɹwɝd tə dɪfɛn hɪm. nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ɛɡwin.

Again, his attacks missed. It seemed he was off by only a few hairs. Celark stumbled to the floor with a gurgle, his blood reflecting lanternlight, and Gawyn couldn't step forward to defend him. Not without exposing Egwene.

wʌn ə ði əsæsənz tɝn bæk tə ɡɔɪn waɪl ði ʌðɝ bɪhɛɾɪd sɛlɑɹk, wɪð ə slæʃ ðət -  dɪspaɪt ðə ʃædoʊz - lʊkt ə lɑt laɪk ðə ɹɪvɝ ʌndɝkʌts ðə bæŋk, ɡɔɪn stɛp bæk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə fɔlən mæn. dɪfɛnd. hi oʊnli hæd tə dɪfɛn əntɪl hɛlp keɪm! hi ɛdʒ tə ðə saɪd.

One of the assassins turned back to Gawyn while the other beheaded Celark, with a slash that -  despite the shadows - looked a lot like The River Undercuts the Bank, Gawyn stepped back, trying to keep his eyes off the fallen man. Defend. He only had to defend until help came! He edged to the side.

ðə sintʃæn wɝ wɛɹi; ðeɪ nu hid fɔt wʌn ə ðɛm ɔf bɪfɔɹ.

The Seanchan were wary; they knew he'd fought one of them off before.

bʌt ðeɪ hæd sətʃ ə stʃɹɔŋ ædvæntɪdʒ. ɡɔɪn wɑzn sɝɾən i kəd stæn əɡɛns tu ʌv ðɛm.

But they had such a strong advantage. Gawyn wasn't certain he could stand against two of them.

jɛs jə wɪl, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf stɝnli. ɪf jə fɔl, ɛɡɪvin daɪz.

Yes you will, he told himself sternly. If you fall, Egivene dies.

wɑz ðəɾ ə flɪkɝ ə muvmən fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɹum? kəd hɛlp əv kʌm? ɡɔɪn fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ə hoʊp, ən ɛdʒ tə ðə saɪd. fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi kəd si mɑzoʊniz bɑɾi ɑn ɹə flɔɹ, bliɾɪŋ.

Was that a flicker of movement from the other room? Could help have come? Gawyn felt a surge of hope, and edged to the side. From there, he could see Mazone's body on rhe floor, bleeding.

ə θɝd ʃæɾoʊd fɪɡjɝ ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪndə ðə ɹum ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn lɑkɪŋ ɪt. ðət wɑz waɪ ði ʌðɝ tu hæd bɪn hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ. ðeɪd wɑntəd tə weɪɾ əntɪl ðɛɹ ælaɪ ɝaɪvd.

A third shadowed figure glided into the room and shut the door behind locking it. That was why the other two had been hesitating. They'd wanted to wait until their ally arrived.

ðə θɹi ʌv əm ətæk təɡɛðɝ.

The three of them attacked together.

pɛɹɪn lɛt ðə wʊlf fɹi.

Perrin let the wolf free.

fəɹ wʌns, hi dɪdnt wɝi əbaʊt wʌɾ ɪt wəd də tə hɪm. hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi, ən əz i fɔt, ðə wɝl sim tə bɪkʌm ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm.

For once, he didn't worry about what it would do to him. He let himself be, and as he fought, the world seemed to become right around him.

pɝhæps ðət wɑz kəz ɪt bɛn tə hɪz wɪl.

Perhaps that was because it bent to his will.

jʌŋ bʊl lɛp fɹəm ə ɹuftɑp ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, paʊɝfəl haɪn lɛɡz spɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ði ɛɹ, tɛɹæŋɡɹil paʊtʃ fæsən tə hɪz bæk. hi sɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ə stʃɹiɾ ən lændəɾ ɑn ə waɪt mɑɹbəl ɹuf wɪð ɡɹups ə stætʃuz ɑn ɪts ɛdʒəz. hi ɹoʊld, kʌmɪŋ ʌp əz ə mæn - tɛɹæŋɡɹil taɪɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst -  wɪð hæmɝ swɪŋɪŋ.

Young Bull leaped from a rooftop in Tar Valon, powerful hind legs springing him into the air, ter'angreal pouch fastened to his back. He soared over a street and landed on a white marble roof with groups of statues on its edges. He rolled, coming up as a man - ter'angreal tied at his waist -  with hammer swinging.

sleɪɝ vænɪʃt ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə hæmɝ hɪt, ðən əpɪɹd bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn. pɛɹɪn vænɪʃt əz sleɪɝ swʌŋ, ðən əpɪɹd dʒʌs tə ðə lɛft. bæk ən fɔɹθ ðeɪ wɛnt, spɪnɪŋ ɝaʊnd wʌn ənʌðɝ, itʃ dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ðən əpɪɹɪŋ əɡɛn, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə læn ə bloʊ.

Slayer vanished right before the hammer hit, then appeared beside Perrin. Perrin vanished as Slayer swung, then appeared just to the left. Back and forth they went, spinning around one another, each disappearing then appearing again, struggling to land a blow.

pɛɹɪn θɹu hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə saɪkəl, sɛndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə ə pleɪs bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə ɹufs lɑɹdʒ stætʃuz, ə pɑmpəs-lʊkɪŋ dʒɛnɝəl. hi swʌŋ, smæʃɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ ɪndə ɪt, mæɡnəfaɪɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ə ðə bloʊ. tʃʌŋks ə stætʃu ɪksploʊɾəd təwɔɹd sleɪɝ. ðə wʊlf-kɪlɝ əpɪɹd, ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə faɪn pɛɹɪn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪnstɛd, ə stɔɹm ə stoʊn ən dʌs kɹæʃt ɪndə hɪm.

Perrin threw himself out of the cycle, sending himself to a place beside one of the roof's large statues, a pompous-looking general. He swung, smashing his hammer into it, magnifying the power of the blow. Chunks of statue exploded toward Slayer. The wolf-killer appeared, expecting to find Perrin beside him. Instead, a storm of stone and dust crashed into him.

sleɪɝ bɛloʊd, stoʊn tʃɪps slaɪsɪŋ ɪz skɪn. hɪz kloʊk ɪmiɾiətli bɪkeɪm əz stʃɹɔŋ əz stil, ɹəflɛktɪŋ tʃʌŋks ə stoʊn. hi wɪpt ɪt bæk ən ði ɪntaɪɝ bɪldɪŋ stɑɹɾəd tə ʃeɪk. pɛɹɪn kɝst ən lɛp fɹi əz ðə ɹuf fɛl ɪn.

Slayer bellowed, stone chips slicing his skin. His cloak immediately became as strong as steel, reflecting chunks of stone. He whipped it back and the entire building started to shake. Perrin cursed and leaped free as the roof fell in.

pɛɹɪn sɔɹd, bɪkʌmɪŋ ə wʊlf bɪfɔɹ lændɪŋ ɑn ə nɪɹbaɪ ɹuftɑp-sleɪɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, baʊ dʒɹɔn. jʌŋ bʊl ɡɹaʊld, ɪmædʒɪn-ɪŋ ðə wɪn bloʊɪŋ, bʌt sleɪɝ dɪdn faɪɝ. hi dʒʌst stʊd ðɛɹ, əz ɪf -  əz ɪf i wɝ dʒʌst ə stætʃu.

Perrin soared, becoming a wolf before landing on a nearby rooftop-Slayer appeared in front of him, bow drawn. Young Bull growled, imagin-ing the wind blowing, but Slayer didn't fire. He just stood there, as if -  As if he were just a statue.

pɛɹɪn kɝst, spɪnɪŋ əz ən æɹoʊ ʃɑt pæs hɪm, nɛɹoʊli mɪsɪŋ ɪm ət ðə weɪst. ðə ɹil sleɪɝ stʊɾ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns ɔf; hi vænɪʃt, livɪŋ ðə ɹɪmɑɹkəbli dɪteɪl stætʃu hid kɹieɪɾəd tə dɪstʃɹæk pɛɹɪn.

Perrin cursed, spinning as an arrow shot past him, narrowly missing him at the waist. The real Slayer stood a short distance off; he vanished, leaving the remarkably detailed statue he'd created to distract Perrin.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən meɪd ðə swɛt liv ɪz bɹaʊ. sleɪɝ kəd kʌm əɾ ɪm fɹəm ɛni dɝɛkʃən. hi pʊɾ ə wɔl əɾ ɪz bæk ən stʊd ɹifəli, skænɪŋ ðə ɹuftɑp. ðə doʊm ʃʊk oʊvɝhɛd. hid ɡɹoʊn juz tə ðət - ɪt muvd wɪð hɪm.

Perrin took a deep breath and made the sweat leave his brow. Slayer could come at him from any direction. He put a wall at his back and stood refully, scanning the rooftop. The dome shook overhead. He'd grown used to that - it moved with him.

bʌɾ i wɑzn muvɪŋ.

But he wasn't moving.

hi lʊk daʊn wɪð ə pænɪk. ðə paʊtʃ wɑz ɡɔn - ði æɹoʊ sleɪɝ hæd faɪɝɾ əɾ ɪz weɪs hæd slaɪst ɪt fɹi. pɛɹɪn dæʃt fɔɹwɝd tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹuf. bɪloʊ, sleɪɝ ɹæn θɹu ðə stʃɹit, ðə paʊtʃ ɪn ɪz hænd.

He looked down with a panic. The pouch was gone - the arrow Slayer had fired at his waist had sliced it free. Perrin dashed forward to the edge of the roof. Below, Slayer ran through the street, the pouch in his hand.

ə wʊlf lɛp fɹəm ən æli, kɹæʃɪŋ ɪndə sleɪɝ, tɔsɪŋ ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɑpɝ.

A wolf leaped from an alley, crashing into Slayer, tossing him to the ground. Hopper.

pɛɹɪn wɑz ðəɹ ɪn ə moʊmənt, ətækɪŋ. sleɪɝ kɝst, vænɪʃɪŋ fɹəm ʌndɝniθ hɑpɝ ən əpɪɹɪŋ ət ði ɛn ə ðə stʃɹit. hi bɪɡæn tə fli, livɪŋ ə blɝ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Perrin was there in a moment, attacking. Slayer cursed, vanishing from underneath Hopper and appearing at the end of the street. He began to flee, leaving a blur behind him.

pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, hɑpɝ dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɪm. haʊ dɪd jə faɪn mi? pɛɹɪn sɛnt.

Perrin followed, Hopper joining him. How did you find me? Perrin sent.

jə ɑɹ tu fulɪʃ kʌbz, hɑpɝ sɛnt. vɛɹi laʊd. laɪk snɑɹlɪŋ kæts. izi tə faɪnd.

You are two foolish cubs, Hopper sent. Very loud. Like snarling cats. Easy to find.

hid dɪlɪbɝətli nɑt ʃoʊn hɑpɝ wɛɹ i wɑz. æftɝ siɪŋ oʊk dænsɝ daɪ . . . wɛl, ðɪs wɑz pɛɹɪnz faɪt. naʊ ðət ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz əweɪ fɹəm ɡildən ən ɪz pipəl wɝ ɪskeɪpɪŋ, hi dɪdnt wɑnə ɹɪsk ðə laɪvz ʌv ʌðɝ wʊlvz.

He'd deliberately not shown Hopper where he was. After seeing Oak Dancer die . . . well, this was Perrin's fight. Now that the ter'angreal was away from Ghealdan and his people were escaping, he didn't want to risk the lives of other wolves.

nɑt ðət hɑpɝ wəd ɡoʊ ɪf i toʊld ɪm tə. ɡɹoʊlɪŋ əɡɛn, pɛɹɪn bæɹəld æftɝ sleɪɝ, wʊlf əɾ ɪz saɪd.

Not that Hopper would go if he told him to. Growling again, Perrin barreled after Slayer, wolf at his side.

ɛɡwin kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪd ðə wɔl ə ðə hɔlweɪ, pæntɪŋ, swɛt dʒɹɪpɪŋ fɹəm əɹ bɹaʊ. əkɹɔs fɹəm hɝ, moʊltən dʒɹɑps ə ɹɑk kul fɹəm ə blæst ə faɪɝ.

Egwene crouched beside the wall of the hallway, panting, sweat dripping from her brow. Across from her, molten drops of rock cooled from a blast of fire.

ðə taʊɝ hɔlweɪ fɛl stɪl. ə fju læmps flɪkɝɾ ɑn ðə wɔl. θɹu ə wɪndoʊ, ʃi kəd si ðə pɝpəl skaɪ əbʌv, bɪtwin ðə taʊɝ ən ðə dɑɹk klaʊdz. ʃid bɪn faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ wʌt sim laɪk aʊɝz, ðoʊ ɪt hæd pɹɑbli bɪn oʊnli fɪftin mɪnəts. ʃid lɔs tʃɹæk ə ðə waɪz wʌnz.

The Tower hallway fell still. A few lamps flickered on the wall. Through a window, she could see the purple sky above, between the Tower and the dark clouds. She'd been fighting for what seemed like hours, though it had probably been only fifteen minutes. She'd lost track of the Wise Ones.

ʃi bɪɡæn tə kɹip fɔɹwɝd, juzɪŋ ði ænti-ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ wiv tə meɪk əɹ fʊtfɔlz saɪlən əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ə kɔɹnɝ ən pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ɪt.

She began to creep forward, using the anti-eavesdropping weave to make her footfalls silent until she reached a corner and peered around it.

dɑɹknəs ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz. ɛɡwin kɹɛp fɔɹwɝd, muvɪŋ kɛɹfəli, ɹɛsəlutli. ðə taʊɝ wɑz əɹ doʊmeɪn. ʃi fɛlt ɪnveɪɾəd, əz ʃʊɹli əz wən ðə sintʃæn hæd kʌm. haʊɛvɝ, ðɪs faɪt wɑz pɹuvɪŋ vɛɹi dɪfɹən fɹəm faɪɾɪŋ ɔf ðə sintʃæn. ðɛɹ, ði ɛnəmi hæd bɪn boʊld, izi tə spɑt.

Darkness in both directions. Egwene crept forward, moving carefully, resolutely. The Tower was her domain. She felt invaded, as surely as when the Seanchan had come. However, this fight was proving very different from fighting off the Seanchan. There, the enemy had been bold, easy to spot.

feɪn laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ʌndɝ ə dɔɹweɪ əhɛd. ʃi ʃɪftəd hɝsɛlf ɪndə ðə ɹum, pɹipɛɹɪŋ wivz.

Faint light appeared under a doorway ahead. She shifted herself into the room, preparing weaves.

tu wɪmən wɝ ðɛɹ, spikɪŋ ɪn wɪspɝz, wʌn hoʊldɪŋ ə ɡloʊb ə laɪt. ɛvænɛlaɪn ən mɛstʃɹə, tu ʌv ðə blæk sɪstɝ u hæd flɛd ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Two women were there, speaking in whispers, one holding a globe of light. Evanellein and Mestra, two of the Black sister who had fled the White Tower.

ɛɡwin lɛt lus wɪð ə bɔl ə faɪɝ ðət dɪstʃɹɔɪd mɛstʃɹə ɪn ən ɪnfɝnoʊ ɛvænɛlaɪn jɛlpt, ən ɛɡwin juzd ə tʃɹɪk nɪneɪiv hæd tɔt hɝ__ʃi ɪmædʒən ɛvænɛlaɪn biɪŋ stupəd, əneɪbəl tə θɪŋk, əneɪbəl tə ɹiækt.

Egwene let loose with a ball of fire that destroyed Mestra in an inferno Evanellein yelped, and Egwene used a trick Nynaeve had taught her__she imagined Evanellein being stupid, unable to think, unable to react.

ðə wʊmənz aɪz ɡleɪzd oʊvɝ, ən əɹ maʊθ oʊpənd. θɔt wɑz fæstɝ ðən wivz. ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. naʊ wʌt? kɪl hɝ, waɪi dɪfɛnsləs? hɝ stʌmək tɝn ət ðət θɔt. / kəd teɪk əɹ kæptɪv. ɡoʊ ən - sʌmwʌn əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹum wɪð hɝ. ðə nukʌmɝ wɔɹ blæk ə mæɡnɪfəsənt ɡaʊn wɪð sɪlvɝ tʃɹɪm. dɑɹknəs swɝld əbaʊt hɝ, meɪɾ ə spɪnɪŋ ɹɪbənz ə klɔθ, hɝ skɝt ɹɪpəlɪŋ. ði ɪfɛkt wɑz ənnætʃɹəl ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv; pɑsəbəl oʊnli hɪɹ ɪn tɛlɝɛɝɝhiəd.

The woman's eyes glazed over, and her mouth opened. Thought was faster than weaves. Egwene hesitated. Now what? Kill her, whiie defenseless? Her stomach turned at that thought. / could take her captive. Go and - Someone appeared in the room with her. The newcomer wore black a magnificent gown with silver trim. Darkness swirled about her, made of spinning ribbons of cloth, her skirt rippling. The effect was unnatural and impressive; possible only here in Tel'ararirhiod.

ɛɡwin lʊkt ɪndə ðə wʊmənz aɪz. lɑɹdʒ ən blu, sɛɾ ɪn ən æŋɡʌ-lɑɹ feɪs wɪð tʃɪn-lɛŋθ blæk hɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz ə paʊɝ tə ðoʊz aɪz, ən ɛɡwin ɪmiɾiətli nu wʌt ʃi wɑz feɪsɪŋ.

Egwene looked into the woman's eyes. Large and blue, set in an angu-lar face with chin-length black hair. There was a power to those eyes, and Egwene immediately knew what she was facing.

waɪ faɪt? ʃi kʊdnt -  ɛɡwin fɛlt əɹ maɪn tʃeɪnʒ, bɪkʌm æksɛptɪŋ. ʃi fɔɾ ɪt wɪð ə bɝst ə pænɪk, ən ɪn ə moʊmən ə klɛɹəɾi, ʃi sɛn hɝsɛlf əweɪ.

Why fight? She couldn't -  Egwene felt her mind change, become accepting. She fought it with a burst of panic, and in a moment of clarity, she sent herself away.

ɛɡwin əpɪɹɾ ɪn əɹ ɹumz, ðən ɹeɪzd əɹ hæn tə hɝ hɛd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə bɛd. laɪt, bʌt ðət wʊmən hæd bɪn stʃɹɔŋ.

Egwene appeared in her rooms, then raised her hand to her head, sitting down on the bed. Light, but that woman had been strong.

sʌmθɪŋ saʊndəd bɪhaɪn hɝ; sʌmwʌn əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹum. ɛɡwin lɛp tə hɝ fit, pɹipɛɹɪŋ wivz. nɪneɪiv stʊd ðɛɹ, aɪz waɪd wɪð fjʊɹi. ðə wʊmən θɹʌst əɹ hænz fɔɹwɝd, wivz fɔɹmɪŋ, bʌt ʃi fɹoʊz.

Something sounded behind her; someone appearing in the room. Egwene leaped to her feet, preparing weaves. Nynaeve stood there, eyes wide with fury. The woman thrust her hands forward, weaves forming, but she froze.

"tə ðə ɡɑɹɾənz," ɛɡwin sɛd, nɑt tʃɹʌstɪŋ əɹ kɔɹɾɝz. ʃi ʃʊdn əv kʌm hɪɹ; mɛsænə wəd noʊ ðɪs pleɪs.

"To the gardens," Egwene said, not trusting her quarters. She shouldn't have come here; Mesaana would know this place.

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd, ən ɛɡwin vænɪʃt, əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə loʊɝ taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾən. ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ vaɪəlɪt doʊm ɪkstɛndəɾ əbʌv. wʌt wɑz ðæt, ən haʊ hæd mɛsænə bɹɔɾ ɪt hɪɹ? nɪneɪiv əpɪɹɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ.

Nynaeve nodded, and Egwene vanished, appearing in the lower Tower garden. The strange violet dome extended above. What was that, and how had Mesaana brought it here? Nynaeve appeared a moment later.

"ðeɪɹ stɪl ʌp ðɛɹ," nɪneɪiv wɪspɝd. "aɪ dʒʌst sɔ ɑlviɛɝɪn."

"They're still up there," Nynaeve whispered. "I just saw Alviarin."

"aɪ sɔ mɛsænə," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ʃi nɪɹli tʊk mi."

"I saw Mesaana," Egwene said. "She nearly took me."

"laɪt! ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"Light! Are you all right?"

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. "mɛstʃɹə ɪz dɛd. aɪ sɔ ɛvænɛlaɪn, tu."

Egwene nodded. "Mestra is dead. I saw Evanellein, too."

"ɪts blæk əz ə tum ʌp ðɛɹ," nɪneɪiv wɪspɝd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪt ðət weɪ. sɪuən ən lin ɑɹ ɔl ɹaɪt; aɪ sɔ ðɛm ə lɪɾəl bɪɾ əɡoʊ, stɪkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðæt, aɪ mænədʒ tə hɪt noʊtoʊfi wɪð ə blæs faɪɝ. ʃiz dɛd."

"It's black as a tomb up there," Nynaeve whispered. "I think they made it that way. Siuan and Leane are all right; I saw them a little bit ago, sticking together. Just before that, I managed to hit Notofi with a blast fire. She's dead."

"ɡʊd. ðə blæk ədʒɑ stoʊl naɪntin tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ðət maɪt ɡɪv əs ən ɛstəməɾ ə haʊ mɛni blæk ədʒɑ wɪv tə kəntɛnd wɪð." ʃi, sɪuən, nɪneɪiv, lin ən ðə θɹi waɪz wʌnz wɝ aʊtnʌmbɝd - bʌt ðə læk ədʒɑ dɪdn sim tə hæv mʌtʃ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

"Good. The Black Ajah stole nineteen ter'angreal. That might give us an estimate of how many Black Ajah we have to contend with." She, Siuan, Nynaeve, Leane and the three Wise Ones were outnumbered - but the Rlack Ajah didn't seem to have much experience with Tel'aran'rhiod.

"hæv jə sin ðə waɪz wʌnz?"

"Have you seen the Wise Ones?"

"ðeɪɹ ʌp ðɛɹ." nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪməst. "ðeɪ sim tə bi ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðɪs."

"They're up there." Nynaeve grimaced. "They seem to be enjoying this."

"ðeɪ wʊd," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ wɑn jə ən mi tə ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ. wɪl əpɪɹ ɪn ɪntɝsɛkʃənz, bæk tə bæk, ən kwɪkli skæn fəɹ laɪɾ əɹ pipəl. ɪf jə si ə blæk, stʃɹaɪk. ɪf sʌmwʌn siz ju, seɪ 'ɡoʊ' ən wɪl dʒʌmp bæk hɪɹ."

"They would," Egwene said. "I want you and me to go together. We will appear in intersections, back to back, and quickly scan for light or people. If you see a Black, strike. If someone sees you, say 'Go' and we'll jump back here."

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd.

Nynaeve nodded.

"fɝst ɪntɝsɛkʃən ɪz ðə wʌn aʊtsaɪd maɪ ɹum," ɛɡwin sɛd. "hɔlweɪ ɑn ðə saʊθ saɪd. əl flʌɾ ɪt wɪð laɪt; jə bi ɹɛɾi. fɹəm ðɛɹ, wɪl dʒʌmp daʊn wʌn hɔlweɪ, baɪ ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə sɝvəns' ɹæmp. ðən ɑn daʊn ðə laɪn."

"First intersection is the one outside my room," Egwene said. "Hallway on the south side. I'll flood it with light; you be ready. From there, we'll jump down one hallway, by the door into the servants' ramp. Then on down the line."

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd ʃɑɹpli.

Nynaeve nodded sharply.

ðə wɝld wɪŋkt ɝaʊn ɛɡwin. ʃi əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, ən ɪmiɾiətli θɔɾ ə ðə pleɪs lɪt, ɪmpoʊzɪŋ əɹ wɪl əpɑn ɪt. laɪt flʌɾəd ði ɪntaɪɝ speɪs. ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən kɹaʊtʃt nɪɹ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, wɛɹɪŋ waɪt. sɛdɔɹi, wʌn ə ðə blæk sɪstɝz.

The world winked around Egwene. She appeared in the hallway, and immediately thought of the place lit, imposing her will upon it. Light flooded the entire space. A round-faced woman crouched near the side of the wall, wearing white. Sedore, one of the Black sisters.

sɛdɔɹi spʌn, lʊkɪŋ æŋɡɹi, wivz spɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn hɝ. ɛɡwin wɝk fæstɝ, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə kɑləm ə faɪɝ ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ sɛdɔɹi wʊɾə ɹilist əɹ oʊn. noʊ wivz ɑn ɛɡwinz pɑɹt. dʒʌs ðə faɪɝ.

Sedore spun, looking angry, weaves springing up around her. Egwene worked faster, creating a column of fire right before Sedore would have released her own. No weaves on Egwene's part. Just the fire.

ɛɡwin sɔ ðə blæks aɪz oʊpən waɪɾɝ əz ðə faɪɝ ɹɔɹɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. sɛdɔɹi skɹitʃt, bʌt ðət kʌɾ ɔf əz ðə hit kənsum hɝ. hɝ bɝn kɔɹps kəlæps tə ðə flɔɹ, smoʊldɝɪŋ.

Egwene saw the Black's eyes open wider as the fire roared around her. Sedore screeched, but that cut off as the heat consumed her. Her burned corpse collapsed to the floor, smoldering.

ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɪliv bɹɛθ. "ɛniwʌn ɑn jəɹ saɪd?"

Egwene let out a relieved breath. "Anyone on your side?"

"noʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "hu wɑz ðət jə hɪt?"

"No," Nynaeve said. "Who was that you hit?"

"sɛdɔɹi."

"Sedore."

"ɹɪli?" nɪneɪiv sɛd, tɝnɪŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə jɛloʊ.

"Really?" Nynaeve said, turning. She had been a Sitter for the Yellow.

ɛɡwin smaɪld. "nɛks hɔlweɪ."

Egwene smiled. "Next hallway."

ðeɪ dʒʌmpt, ən ɹɪpiɾɪd ðɛɹ stʃɹæɾədʒi, flʌɾɪŋ ðə hɔlweɪ wɪð laɪt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊbɑdi ðɛɹ, soʊ ðeɪ muvd ɑn. ðə nɛks tu hɔlweɪz wɝ ɛmpti. ɛɡwin wɑz əbaʊt tə liv wən ə vɔɪs hɪst, "fulɪʃ tʃaɪld! jəɹ pæɾɝn ɪz ɑbviəs."

They jumped, and repeated their strategy, flooding the hallway with light. There was nobody there, so they moved on. The next two hallways were empty. Egwene was about to leave when a voice hissed, "Foolish child! Your pattern is obvious."

ɛɡwin spʌn. "wɛɹ . . ."

Egwene spun. "Where . . ."

ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz ʃi sɔ bɛɹ. ði eɪdʒɪd waɪz wʌn hæd tʃeɪnʒd əɹ klɔθ-ɪŋ ən ivən əɹ skɪn ɪtsɛlf tə mætʃ ðə waɪt wɔlz ən flɔɹ taɪlz. ʃi wɑz pɹæktəkli ɪnvɪzəbəl, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɪn ən ælkoʊv.

She cut off as she saw Bair. The aged Wise One had changed her cloth-ing and even her skin itself to match the white walls and floor tiles. She was practically invisible, crouching in an alcove.

"ju ʃʊdnt - " bɛɹ bɪɡæn.

"You shouldn't - " Bair began.

ə wɔl bɪsaɪɾ əm ɪksploʊɾəd aʊtwɝd, θɹoʊɪŋ ʌp tʃʌŋks ə ɹɑk sɪks wɪmən stʊd bɪɑnd, ən ðeɪ ɹilist wivz ə faɪɝ. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət ðə taɪm fəɹ snikɪŋ hæɾ ɛndəd.

A wall beside them exploded outward, throwing up chunks of rock Six women stood beyond, and they released weaves of Fire. It appeared that the time for sneaking had ended.

pɛɹɪn kɹɛstəd ðə wɔl sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz, kʌmɪŋ daʊn wɪð ə θʌmp. ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim kəntɪnjud; hi naʊ nɑɾ oʊnli smɛld ɑd sɛns, bʌt hɝɾ ɑd saʊnz əz wɛl. ɹʌmbəlɪŋz fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊɝ.

Perrin crested the wall surrounding the White Tower grounds, coming down with a thump. The strangeness of the wolf dream continued; he now not only smelled odd scents, but heard odd sounds as well. Rumblings from inside the Tower.

hi lɛpt æftɝ sleɪɝ, hu kɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnz, ðən ɹæn ʌp ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf.

He leaped after Slayer, who crossed the grounds, then ran up the outside of the Tower itself.

pɛɹɪn fɑloʊd, ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ. sleɪɝ steɪd dʒʌst əhɛd, tɛɹæŋɡɹil paʊtʃ taɪɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst.

Perrin followed, running up into the air. Slayer stayed just ahead, ter'angreal pouch tied at his waist.

pɛɹɪn kɹieɪɾəd ə lɔŋboʊ. hi pʊld ɪt bæk, fɹizɪŋ ɪn pleɪs, stændɪŋ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ.

Perrin created a longbow. He pulled it back, freezing in place, standing on the side of the Tower.

hi lust, bʌt ðə wʊlf-kɪlɝ lɛpt ʌp, ðən fɛl ɪndə ðə taʊɝ θɹu ə wɪndoʊ. ði æɹoʊ pæst oʊvɝhɛd.

He loosed, but the wolf-killer leaped up, then fell into the Tower through a window. The arrow passed overhead.

pɛɹɪn lɛp tə ðə wɪndoʊ, ðən dʌkt ɪnsaɪd, hɑpɝ lipɪŋ ɪn æftɝ hɪm, livɪŋ ə blɝ bɪhaɪnd. ðeɪ ɛntɝɾ ə bɛdʒɹum hʌŋ wɪð bɹoʊkeɪdz ə blu. ðə dɔɹ slæmd, ən pɛɹɪn tʃɑɹdʒd æftɝ sleɪɝ. hi dɪdn bɑðɝ tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ; hi smæʃt ɪt wɪð ɪz hæmɝ.

Perrin leaped to the window, then ducked inside, Hopper leaping in after him, leaving a blur behind. They entered a bedroom hung with brocades of blue. The door slammed, and Perrin charged after Slayer. He didn't bother to open the door; he smashed it with his hammer.

sleɪɝ tʃɑɹdʒ daʊn ə hɔlweɪ.

Slayer charged down a hallway.

fɑloʊ, pɛɹɪn sɛn tə hɑpɝ. əl kʌɾ ɪm ɔf.

Follow, Perrin sent to Hopper. I'll cut him off.

ðə wʊlf ɹeɪs fɔɹwɝd, æftɝ sleɪɝ. pɛɹɪn ɹæn tə ðə ɹaɪt, ðən kʌt daʊn ə hɔlweɪ. hi muv kwɪkli, ðə wɔlz spiɾɪŋ pæst.

The wolf raced forward, after Slayer. Perrin ran to the right, then cut down a hallway. He moved quickly, the walls speeding past.

hi pæst ə hɔlweɪ ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə bi fʊl ə pipəl. hi wɑz soʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i fɹoʊz, ðə hɔl lɝtʃɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm.

He passed a hallway that appeared to be full of people. He was so surprised that he froze, the hall lurching around him.

ðeɪ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðeɪ wɝ faɪɾɪŋ. ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz əlaɪt, tʃɹeɪlz ə faɪɝ flaɪɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ɛn tə ði ʌðɝ. ðə saʊnz hid hɝd bɪfɔɹ hædn bɪn fæntəmz. ænd, hi θɔt, jɛs . . .

They were Aes Sedai, and they were fighting. The hallway was alight, trails of fire flying from one end to the other. The sounds he'd heard before hadn't been phantoms. And, he thought, yes . . .

"ɛɡwin?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Egwene?" Perrin asked.

ʃi stʊd pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə wɔl nɪɹbaɪ, ɪntɛnli lʊkɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. wən i spoʊk, ʃi spʌn ɑn hɪm, hænz ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp. hi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɡɹæb hɪm. hɪz maɪn ɪnstənli ɹiæktəd, haʊɛvɝ, pʊʃɪŋ ði ɛɹ əweɪ ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd əz ʃi feɪl tə snætʃ hɪm.

She stood pressed against the wall nearby, intently looking down the hallway. When he spoke, she spun on him, hands going up. He felt something grab him. His mind instantly reacted, however, pushing the air away Egwene started as she failed to snatch him.

hi stɛp fɔɹwɝd. "ɛɡwin, jə ʃʊdn bi hɪɹ. ðɪs pleɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs."

He stepped forward. "Egwene, you shouldn't be here. This place is dangerous."

"pɛɹɪn?"

"Perrin?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ jə ɡɑt hɪɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌt jə nid tə ɡoʊ. pliz. "haʊ dɪd jə stɑp mi?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ. hæv jə bɪn wɪð ɹænd? tɛl mi wɛɹ i ɪz."

"I don't know how you got here," Perrin said. "But you need to go. Please. "How did you stop me?" she demanded. "What are you doing here. Have you been with Rand? Tell me where he is."

ʃi spoʊk wɪð sətʃ əθɔɹəɾi naʊ. ʃi ɔlmoʊst simd ə dɪfɹən pɝ-sʌn, dɛkeɪdz oʊldɝ ðən ðə ɡɝl hid noʊn. pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə ɹɪplaɪ, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kʌɾ ɪm ɔf.

She spoke with such authority now. She almost seemed a different per-son, decades older than the girl he'd known. Perrin opened his mouth to reply, but Egwene cut him off.

"aɪ doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ ðɪs," ʃi sɛd. "aɪm sɑɹi, pɛɹɪn. əl bi bæk fəɹ ju." ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hænd, ən i fɛl θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ ɝaʊn hɪm. ɹoʊps əpɪɹd, baɪndɪŋ hɪm.

"I don't have time for this," she said. "I'm sorry, Perrin. I'll be back for you." She raised a hand, and he felt things change around him. Ropes appeared, binding him.

hi lʊk daʊn, əmjuzd. ðə ɹoʊps slɪp fɹi ðə moʊmən i θɔɾ ə ðɛm biɪŋ tu lus.

He looked down, amused. The ropes slipped free the moment he thought of them being too loose.

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt, wɑtʃɪŋ əm dʒɹɑp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "haʊ - "

Egwene blinked, watching them drop to the ground. "How - "

sʌmwʌn bɝst aʊɾ ʌv ə ɹum nɪɹbaɪ, ə tɔl, slɛndɝ-nɛkt wʊmən wɪð ɹeɪvən hɛɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ə slik waɪt dʒɹɛs. ʃi smaɪld, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hænz, ən ə laɪɾ əpɪɹd bɪfɔɹ hɝ.

Someone burst out of a room nearby, a tall, slender-necked woman with raven hair, wearing a sleek white dress. She smiled, raising her hands, and a light appeared before her.

pɛɹɪn dɪdnt nid tə noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. hi wɑz ə wʊlf; hi wɑz ðə ɹulɝ ə ðɪs pleɪs.

Perrin didn't need to know what she was doing. He was a wolf; he was the ruler of this place.

wivz wɝ minɪŋləs. hi ɪmædʒən ðə wʊmənz ətæk mɪsɪŋ hɪm; hi nu ɪt wəd bi soʊ.

Weaves were meaningless. He imagined the woman's attack missing him; he knew it would be so.

ə bɑɹ ʌv waɪt-hɑt laɪt ʃɑt fɹəm ðə wʊmən. pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ə hæn bɪfɔɹ hɪmsɛlf ən ɛɡwin.

A bar of white-hot light shot from the woman. Perrin raised a hand before himself and Egwene.

ðə laɪt vænɪʃt, əz ɪf stɑp baɪ hɪz pɑm.

The light vanished, as if stopped by his palm.

ɛɡwin tɝnd, ən ðə wɔl əbʌv ðə wʊmən bɝst, ɹɑk ʃaʊɝɪŋ daʊn. ə tʃʌŋk smæʃt ðə wʊmən ɑn ðə hɛd bɹuɾəli, nɑkɪŋ əɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. laɪt, ʃi wɑz pɹɑbli dɛd, æftɝ ə bloʊ laɪk ðæt.

Egwene turned, and the wall above the woman burst, rock showering down. A chunk smashed the woman on the head brutally, knocking her to the ground. Light, she was probably dead, after a blow like that.

ɛɡwin smɛld əmeɪzd. ʃi spʌn ɑn hɪm. "bɑlfaɪɝ? jə stɑp bɑlfaɪɝ? nʌθɪŋ ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə də ðæt."

Egwene smelled amazed. She spun on him. "Balefire? You stopped balefire? Nothing should be able to do that."

"ɪts dʒʌst ə wiv," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt fəɹ hɑpɝ. wɛɹ wɑz sleɪɝ?

"It's just a weave," Perrin said, reaching out for Hopper. Where was Slayer?

"ɪts nɑt dʒʌst ə wiv, pɛɹɪn, ɪts - "

"It's not just a weave, Perrin, it's - "

"aɪm sɑɹi, ɛɡwin," hi sɛd. "aɪ wɪl spik tə jə leɪɾɝ. bi kɛɹfəl ɪn ðɪs pleɪs. jə pɹɑbli ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ðət jə nid tə bi, bʌt stɪl. ɪts mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən jə noʊ."

"I'm sorry, Egwene," he said. "I will speak to you later. Be careful in this place. You probably already know that you need to be, but still. It's more dangerous than you know."

hi tɝn ən ɹæn, livɪŋ ɛɡwin spʌɾɝɪŋ. ɪt simd ʃid mænədʒ tə bɪkʌm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

He turned and ran, leaving Egwene sputtering. It seemed she'd managed to become an Aes Sedai.

ðət wɑz ɡʊd; ʃi dɪzɝvd ɪt.

That was good; she deserved it.

hɑpɝ? hi sɛnt. wɛɹ ɑɹ ju?

Hopper? he sent. Where are you?

hɪz oʊnli ɹɪplaɪ wɑz ə sʌɾən, tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ, sɛndɪŋ ə peɪn.

His only reply was a sudden, terrifying, sending of pain.

ɡɔɪn fɔt fəɹ ɪz laɪf əɡɛns θɹi lɪvɪŋ ʃædoʊz ə dɑɹknəs ən stil ðeɪ pɹɛst ɪm tə ði ʌtmoʊst ə hɪz əbɪləɾi, livɪŋ ɪm blʌɾid hæf ə dʌzən taɪmz oʊvɝ ɑn ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz. hi juz ðə sɪkloʊn ɹeɪdʒɪz, ən ɪt dɪfɛndəɾ ɪz vaɪɾəlz. bɛɹli.

Gawyn fought for his life against three living shadows of darkness and steel They pressed him to the utmost of his ability, leaving him bloodied half a dozen times over on arms and legs. He used The Cyclone Rages, and it defended his vitals. Barely.

dʒɹɑps ə hɪz blʌd steɪn ðə ɡɔz dʒɹeɪpɪŋ ɛɡwinz bɛd. ɪf ɪz əpoʊnəns hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi kɪld ɛɡwin, ðən ðeɪ meɪɾ ə ɡʊd ʃoʊ ʌv kɑn-tɪnjuɪŋ tə θɹɛɾən hɝ.

Drops of his blood stained the gauze draping Egwene's bed. If his opponents had already killed Egwene, then they made a good show of con-tinuing to threaten her.

hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ wik ən taɪɝd. hɪz buts lɛf blʌɾi pɹɪns wən i stɛpt. hi kʊdn fil ðə peɪn. hɪz pɛɹiz wɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ slʌɡɪʃ. ðeɪɾ əv ɪm ɪn ənʌðɝ moʊmən əɹ tu.

He was growing weak and tired. His boots left bloody prints when he stepped. He couldn't feel the pain. His parries were becoming sluggish. They'd have him in another moment or two.

noʊ hɛlp keɪm, ɔlðoʊ hɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɔɹs fɹəm jɛlɪŋ. ful! hi θɔt. jə nid tə spɛn mɔɹ taɪm θɪŋkɪŋ ən lɛs taɪm ɹʌnɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə deɪnʒɝ! hi ʃʊɾə əlɝɾɪd ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ.

No help came, although his voice was hoarse from yelling. Fool! he thought. You need to spend more time thinking and less time running straight into danger! He should have alerted the entire Tower.

ði oʊnli ɹizən i wɑz əlaɪv wɑz kəz ðə θɹi wɝ biɪŋ kɛɹfəl wɛɹɪŋ ɪm daʊn. wʌns i fɛl, ðət sʌldəm hæɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ ɑn ə ɹæmpeɪdʒ θɹu ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɪt wəd teɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmplitli baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. ðɪs naɪt kəd bi ə dɪzæstɝ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ði ɝɪdʒənəl sintʃæn stʃɹaɪk hæd bɪn.

The only reason he was alive was because the three were being careful wearing him down. Once he fell, that sul'dam had indicated they would go on a rampage through the White Tower. It would take the Aes Sedai completely by surprise. This night could be a disaster greater than the original Seanchan strike had been.

ðə θɹi muv fɔɹwɝd.

The three moved forward.

noʊ! ɡɔɪn θɔɾ əz wʌn ə ðɛm tʃɹaɪd ðə ɹɪvɝ ʌndɝkʌts ðə bæŋk. hi lɛp fɔɹwɝd, dɑdʒɪŋ bɪtwin tu bleɪdz, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz wɛpən. əmeɪzɪŋli, hi æktʃəli  stʃɹʌk, ən ə vɔɪs kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹum. blʌd spɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wʌn ʃæɾoʊi fɔɹm fɔlɪŋ.

No! Gawyn thought as one of them tried The River Undercuts the Bank. He leaped forward, dodging between two blades, swinging his weapon. Amazingly, he actually struck, and a voice cried out in the room. Blood sprayed across the ground, one shadowy form falling.

ðə tu ʌðɝz mʌɾɝd kɝsɪz, ən ɔl pɹitɛns ʌv wɛɹɪŋ ɪm daʊn vænɪʃt. ðeɪ stʃɹʌk ət hɪm, wɛpənz flæʃɪŋ əmɪd dɑɹk mɪst. ɪɡzɔstəd, ɡɔɪn tʊk ənʌðɝ hɪɾ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ, blʌd tʃɹɪklɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɑɹm bɪniθ ɪz koʊt.

The two others muttered curses, and all pretense of wearing him down vanished. They struck at him, weapons flashing amid dark mist. Exhausted, Gawyn took another hit on the shoulder, blood trickling down his arm beneath his coat.

ʃædoʊz. haʊ kəɾ ə mæn bi ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪɾ əɡɛnst ʃædoʊz? ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl!

Shadows. How could a man be expected to fight against shadows? It was impossible!

wɛɹ ðəɹ ɪz laɪt, ðəɹ mʌs bi ʃædoʊ . . .

Where there is light, there must be shadow . . .

ə læst, dɛspɹɪt θɔɾ əkɝd tə hɪm. wɪð ə kɹaɪ, hi lɛp tə ðə saɪɾ ən jæŋkt ə pɪloʊ fɹəm ɛɡwinz bɛd. bleɪdz kʌt ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɪm əz i spʌn ən slæm ðə pɪloʊ ɑn ðə læntɝn, smʌðɝɪŋ ɪt.

A last, desperate thought occurred to him. With a cry, he leaped to the side and yanked a pillow from Egwene's bed. Blades cut the air around him as he spun and slammed the pillow on the lantern, smothering it.

plʌnʒɪŋ ðə ɹum ɪndə dɑɹknəs. noʊ laɪt. noʊ ʃædoʊz.

Plunging the room into darkness. No light. No shadows.

ɪkwɑləɾi.

Equality.

ðə dɑɹknəs ivən aʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən ɪn ðə naɪt, jə kʊdn si kʌlɝ. hi kʊdn si ðə blʌɾ ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz, kʊdn si ðə blæk ʃædoʊz ə hɪz ɛnəmiz əɹ ðə waɪtnəs ʌv ɛɡwinz bɛd.

The darkness evened out everything, and in the night, you couldn't see color. He couldn't see the blood on his arms, couldn't see the black shadows of his enemies or the whiteness of Egwene's bed.

bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ ðə mɛn muv.

But he could hear the men move.

hi ɹeɪzd ɪz bleɪd fəɹ ə dɛspɹɪt stʃɹaɪk, juzɪŋ hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz, pɹɪdɪktɪŋ wɛɹ ðə blʌdnaɪvz wəd muv. hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ ðɛɹ mɪstɪd fɪɡjɝz, ən ɪz stʃɹaɪk hɪt tʃɹu, sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə flɛʃ.

He raised his blade for a desperate strike, using Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose, predicting where the Bloodknives would move. He was no longer distracted by their misted figures, and his strike hit true, sinking into flesh.

hi twɪstəd, jæŋkɪŋ ɪz bleɪd fɹi. ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlən seɪv fəɹ ðə fɔl ə ðə mæn hid hɪt. ɡɔɪn hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ, hɑɹtbit θʌmpɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. wɛɹ wɑz ðə læst əsæsən?

He twisted, yanking his blade free. The room fell silent save for the fall of the man he'd hit. Gawyn held his breath, heartbeat thumping in his ears. Where was the last assassin?

noʊ laɪt keɪm ɪn fɹəm ðə ɹum nɛks dɔɹ; sɛlɑɹk hæd fɔlən bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ, blɑkɪŋ ðə laɪɾ ʌndɝniθ.

No light came in from the room next door; Celark had fallen beside the doorway, blocking the light underneath.

ɡɔɪn wɑz filɪŋ ʃeɪki naʊ. hid lɔs tu mʌtʃ blʌd. ɪf i hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə θɹoʊ tə kɹieɪɾ ə dɪstʃɹækʃən . . . bʌt noʊ. muvɪŋ wəd ɹʌsəl kloʊðɪŋ, wəd ɡɪv ɪm əweɪ.

Gawyn was feeling shaky now. He'd lost too much blood. If he had something to throw to create a distraction . . . but no. Moving would rustle clothing, would give him away.

soʊ, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ, hi tæpt ɪz fʊɾ ən ɹeɪzd ɪz bleɪd tə pɹətɛkt ɪz nɛk, pɹeɪɪŋ tə ðə laɪt ðət ði ətæk keɪm loʊ.

So, gritting his teeth, he tapped his foot and raised his blade to protect his neck, praying to the Light that the attack came low.

ɪt dɪd, kʌɾɪŋ dipli ɪndə hɪz saɪd. hi tʊk ɪt wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, bʌɾ ɪmiɾiətli læʃt aʊt wɪð ɔl i hæd. hɪz sɔɹd hɪst, ən wɪð ə bɹif tʌɡ ɪt slaɪs tʃɹu. ə θʌmp fɑloʊd; ə dikæpəteɪɾɪd hɛd baʊnsɪŋ ɔf ðə wɔl, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə nɔɪz ʌv ə kɔɹps hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

It did, cutting deeply into his side. He took it with a grunt, but immediately lashed out with all he had. His sword hissed, and with a brief tug it sliced true. A thump followed; a decapitated head bouncing off the wall, followed by the noise of a corpse hitting the ground.

ɡɔɪn slʌmpt əɡɛns ðə bɛd, blʌd ɡʌʃɪŋ fɹəm ɪz saɪd. hi wɑz blækɪŋ aʊt, ɔlðoʊ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl ɪn ði ənlɪt ɹum.

Gawyn slumped against the bed, blood gushing from his side. He was blacking out, although it was hard to tell in the unlit room.

hi ɹitʃt fəɹ wɛɹ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɛɡwinz hæn biɪŋ, bʌt wɑz tu wik tə faɪn ɪt.

He reached for where he remembered Egwene's hand being, but was too weak to find it.

hi hɪt ðə flɔɹ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ. hɪz læs θɔt wɑz ðəɾ i stɪl dɪdnt noʊ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi wɑz dɛd.

He hit the floor a moment later. His last thought was that he still didn't know whether or not she was dead.

"ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," keɪɾɝin sɛd, nilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ mɛsænə, "wi kænɑt faɪn ðə θɪŋ jə dɪskɹaɪb.

"Great Mistress," Katerine said, kneeling before Mesaana, "we cannot find the thing you describe.

hæf ʌv əɹ wɪmən sɝtʃ fəɹ ɪt waɪl ði ʌðɝ hæf faɪt ðə wɝmz u ɹɪzɪst. bʌɾ ɪts noʊwɛɹ!"

Half of our women search for it while the other half fight the worms who resist. But it is nowhere!"

mɛsænə foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts əz ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən. wɪð ən ɑfhændɪd θɔt, ʃi stʃɹæp keɪɾɝinz bæk wɪð laɪnz ʌv ɛɹ. feɪljɝ niɾəd ɔlweɪz bi pʌnɪʃt.

Mesaana folded her arms beneath her breasts as she considered the situation. With an offhanded thought, she strapped Katerine's back with lines of Air. Failure needed always be punished.

kənsɪstənsi wɑz ðə ki ɪn ɔl fɔɹmz ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɹʌmbəld əbʌv hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz seɪf hɪɹ. ʃiɾ ɪmpoʊzd əɹ wɪl ɑn ðɪs ɛɹiə, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə nu ɹum bɪniθ ðə beɪsməns, kɑɹvd əz ə pɑkəɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən u fɔɾ əbʌv ɑbviəsli nɔt ðɛmsɛlvz pɹæktəst ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, bʌt tʃɪlʒɹən ðeɪ wɝ. ʃi hæd bɪn kʌmɪŋ tə tɛlɝɑnɹbiəd fəɹ ə sɛntʃɝi bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɪmpɹɪzənmənt. ðə taʊɝ ɹʌmbəld əɡɛn. kɛɹfəli, ʃi kənsɪɾɝd əɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən.

Consistency was the key in all forms of training. The White Tower rumbled above her, though she was safe here. She'd imposed her will on this area, creating a new room beneath the basements, carved as a pocket in the stone. The children who fought above obviously nought themselves practiced in this place, but children they were. She had been coming to Tel'aran'rbiod for a century before her imprisonment. The Tower rumbled again. Carefully, she considered her situation.

sʌmhaʊ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd faʊn ə dʒɹimspaɪk. haʊ hæd ðeɪ loʊkeɪɾəd sətʃ ə tʃɹɛʒɝ? mɛsænə wɑz nɪɹli əz ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɡeɪnɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ʌv ɪɾ əz ʃi wɑz ɪn dɑməneɪɾɪŋ ðə tʃaɪld æmɪɝlɪn, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. ði əbɪləɾi tə fɝbɪd ɡeɪtweɪz ɪndə jəɹ pleɪsəz ə ɹɛfjudʒ . . . wɛl, ɪt wɑz ə vaɪɾəl tul, pɑɹtɪkjəlɛɹi wən ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə muv əɡɛns ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən. ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv ðən wɔɹdz, pɹətɛktɪŋ wʌnz dʒɹimz fɹəm ɛni ɪntʃɹuʒən, ən ɪt stɑpt ɔl fɔɹmz ə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn əɹ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹiə ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz æl-loʊd.

somehow, the Aes Sedai had found a dreamspike. How had they located such a treasure? Mesaana was nearly as interested in gaining control of it as she was in dominating the child Amyrlin, Egwene al'Vere. The ability to forbid gateways into your places of refuge . . . Well, it was a vital tool, particulary when she decided to move against the other Chosen. It was more effective than wards, protecting one's dreams from any intrusion, and it stopped all forms of Traveling in or out of the area except for those al-lowed.

haʊɛvɝ, wɪð ðə dʒɹimspaɪk ɪn pleɪs, ʃi ɔlsoʊ kəd nɑt muv ðɪs bæɾəl wɪð ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əbʌv tə ə mɔɹ suɾəbəl, kɛɹfəli səlɛktəd loʊkə-ʃən. æɡɹəveɪɾɪŋ. bʌt noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ hɝsɛlf tə bɪkʌm ɛɹnoʊ-ʃənəl əbaʊt ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən.

However, with the dreamspike in place, she also could not move this battle with the children above to a more suitable, carefully selected loca-tion. Aggravating. But no, she would not allow herself to become erno-tional about the situation.

"ɹɪtɝn əbʌv ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn kæptʃɝɪŋ ðə wʊmən ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," mɛsænə sɛd. "ʃi wɪl noʊ wɛɹ ðə dɪvaɪs ɪz." jɛs ðət wɑz klɪɹ tə hɝ naʊ. ʃi wəɾ ətʃiv tu vɪktɝiz wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl ækt "jɛs . . . mɪstʃɹəs . . ." keɪɾɝin wɑz stɪl kaʊɝɪŋ, stʃɹæps ʌv ɛɹ biɾɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ bæk. ɑ, jɛs. mɛsænə weɪv kɝtli, dɪspɛlɪŋ ðə wiv. əz ʃi dɪd soʊ, ə θɔɾ əkɝd tə hɝ.

"Return above and concentrate everything on capturing the woman Egwene al'Vere," Mesaana said. "She will know where the device is." Yes that was clear to her now. She would achieve two victories with a single act "Yes . . . Mistress . . ." Katerine was still cowering, straps of Air beating against her back. Ah, yes. Mesaana waved curtly, dispelling the weave. As she did so, a thought occurred to her.

"weɪt hɪɹ, ə moʊmənt," ʃi sɛd tə keɪɾɝin. "aɪm gɑnə pleɪs ə wiv əpɑn ju. . . ."

"Wait here, a moment," she said to Katerine. "I'm going to place a weave upon you. . . ."

pɛɹɪn əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə vɛɹi tɑp ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Perrin appeared on the very top of the White Tower.

sleɪɝ hɛl hɑpɝ baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə hɪz nɛk. ðə wʊlf hæɾ ən æɹoʊ θɹu hɪz saɪd; blʌd ɹæn daʊn ɪz pɔ. wɪn blu əkɹɔs ðə ɹɑk, kætʃɪŋ ðə blʌɾ ən spɹeɪɪŋ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə stoʊnz.

Slayer held Hopper by the scruff of his neck. The wolf had an arrow through his side; blood ran down his paw. Wind blew across the rock, catching the blood and spraying it across the stones.

"hɑpɝ!" pɛɹɪn tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd. hi kəd stɪl sɛns hɑpɝz maɪnd, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz wik.

"Hopper!" Perrin took a step forward. He could still sense Hopper's mind, though it was weak.

sleɪɝ hɛl ðə wʊlf ʌp, lɪftɪŋ ɪm izəli. hi ɹeɪzd ə naɪf.

Slayer held the wolf up, lifting him easily. He raised a knife.

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ju hæv wʌt jə wɑnt. dʒʌst ɡoʊ."

"No," Perrin said. "You have what you want. Just go."

"And what was it you said earlier?" Slayer asked. "That you know where I would go, and you'd follow? The dreamspike is too easy to locate on this side."

hi kæʒəwəli tɔs ðə wʊlf ɔf ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ.

He casually tossed the wolf off the side of the Tower.

"noʊ!" pɛɹɪn skɹimd. hi lɛp fəɹ ðə saɪd, bʌt sleɪɝ əpɪɹd bɪsaɪd hɪm, ɡɹæbɪŋ hɪm, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz dæɡɝ. ðə lip nɑkt əm boʊθ ɔf ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, pɛɹɪnz stʌmək lɝtʃɪŋ əz ðeɪ fɛl.

"NO!" Perrin screamed. He leaped for the side, but Slayer appeared beside him, grabbing him, raising his dagger. The leap knocked them both off the side of the Tower, Perrin's stomach lurching as they fell.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə sɛn hɪmsɛlf əweɪ, bʌt sleɪɝ hæd hoʊld ə hɪm, ən i tʃɹaɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd tə kip əm ɪn pleɪs. ðeɪ ʃʊk fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt kɛp fɔlɪŋ.

He tried to send himself away, but Slayer had hold of him, and he tried very hard to keep them in place. They shook for a moment, but kept falling.

sleɪɝ wɑz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ. hi smɛld ɹɔŋ, laɪk steɪlnəs ən wʊlfs blʌd. hɪz naɪf sɔt pɛɹɪnz θɹoʊt, ən ðə bɛs pɛɹɪn kəd də wɑz ɹeɪz ɪz ɑɹm tə blɑk, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɪz ʃɝt biɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz stil.

Slayer was so strong. He smelled wrong, like staleness and wolf's blood. His knife sought Perrin's throat, and the best Perrin could do was raise his arm to block, thinking of his shirt being as hard as steel.

sleɪɝ pɹɛs hɑɹɾɝ. pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə moʊmən ʌv wiknəs, ðə waʊn əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛs θɹɑbɪŋ əz i ən sleɪɝ tʌmbəld. ðə naɪf splɪt pɝ-ɹɪnz sliv ən ɹæmd ɪndə hɪz fɔɹɑɹm.

Slayer pressed harder. Perrin felt a moment of weakness, the wound across his chest throbbing as he and Slayer tumbled. The knife split Per-rin's sleeve and rammed into his forearm.

pɛɹɪn skɹimd. ðə wɪnd wɑz soʊ laʊd. ɪt hæd bɪn mɪɹ sɛkənz. sleɪɝ pʊl ðə naɪf fɹi.

Perrin screamed. The wind was so loud. It had been mere seconds. Slayer pulled the knife free.

hɑpɝ!

Hopper!

pɛɹɪn ɹɔɹɾ ən kɪkt ət sleɪɝ, pʊʃɪŋ ɪm əweɪ, bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪz ɡɹɪp. ɑɹm əfleɪm, pɛɹɪn twɪstəɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ. ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹʌʃt ət ðɛm. hi wɪl hɪmsɛlf tə ənʌðɝ pleɪs, ən i əpɪɹd dʒʌs bɪloʊ hɑpɝ, kætʃɪŋ ðə wʊlf ən kɹæʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz niz bʌkəld; ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn ɪm ʃæɾɝd. bʌɾ i loʊɝd hɑpɝ seɪfli.

Perrin roared and kicked at Slayer, pushing him away, breaking his grip. Arm aflame, Perrin twisted in the air. The ground rushed at them. He willed himself to another place, and he appeared just below Hopper, catching the wolf and crashing into the ground. His knees buckled; the ground around him shattered. But he lowered Hopper safely.

ə blæk-flɛtʃt æɹoʊ zɪp fɹəm ðə skaɪ ən pɪɹs hɑpɝz bæk, pæsɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu ðə wʊlf ən hɪɾɪŋ pɛɹɪn ɪn ɪz θaɪ, wɪtʃ wɑz bɛn ət ðə ni dʒʌs bɪniθ ðə wʊlf.

A black-fletched arrow zipped from the sky and pierced Hopper's back, passing all the way through the wolf and hitting Perrin in his thigh, which was bent at the knee just beneath the wolf.

pɛɹɪn jɛld, filɪŋ ɪz oʊn peɪn mɪks wɪð ə sʌɾən wɑʃ ʌv æɡəni fɹəm hɑpɝ. ðə wʊlfs maɪnd wɑz feɪɾɪŋ.

Perrin yelled, feeling his own pain mix with a sudden wash of agony from Hopper. The wolf's mind was fading.

"noʊ!" pɛɹɪn sɛnt, aɪz wɛt wɪð tɪɹz.

"No!" Perrin sent, eyes wet with tears.

jʌŋ bʊl. . . hɑpɝ sɛnt.

Young Bull. . . Hopper sent.

pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə sɛn hɪmsɛlf əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪz maɪnd wɑz fʌzi. ənʌðɝ æɹoʊ wəd sun fɔl. hi nu ɪt. hi mænədʒ tə ɹoʊl aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ əz ɪt stʃɹʌk ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ ɪz lɛɡ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝkt, ən hɑpɝ wɑz soʊ hɛvi. pɛɹɪn pɪtʃt tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə wʊlf, ɹoʊlɪŋ.

Perrin tried to send himself away, but his mind was fuzzy. Another arrow would soon fall. He knew it. He managed to roll out of the way as it struck the ground, but his leg no longer worked, and Hopper was so heavy. Perrin pitched to the ground, dropping the wolf, rolling.

sleɪɝ lændəɾ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, lɔŋ, wɪkəd blæk baʊ ɪn hænd. "ɡʊdbaɪ, eɪbɑɹə." sleɪɝ ɹeɪzd ɪz baʊ. "lʊks laɪk aɪ kɪl faɪv wʊlvz tədeɪ."

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ʌp ət ði æɹoʊ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz blɝi.

aɪ kæn liv feɪl. aɪ kæn liv hɑpɝ.

aɪ woʊnt!

I won't!

əz sleɪɝ ɹilist, pɛɹɪn dɛspɝətli ɪmædʒən hɪmsɛlf stʃɹɔŋ, nɑt feɪnt. hi fɛlt ɪz hɑɹt bɪkʌm heɪl əɡɛn, hɪz veɪnz fɪlɪŋ wɪð ɛnɝdʒi. hi jɛld, hɛd klɪɹɪŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf vænɪʃ ən əpɪɹ stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn sleɪɝ.

hi swʌŋ wɪð ɪz hæmɝ.

He swung with his hammer.

meɪɝ tɝn kæʒəwəli ən blɑkt ɪt wɪð ɪz ɑɹm, wɪtʃ wɑz ɪnɔɹməsli stʃɹɔŋ. pɛɹɪn fɛl tə wʌn ni, ðə peɪn ɪn ɪz lɛɡ stɪl ðɛɹ. hi ɡæspt.

"You can't heal yourself," Slayer said. "There are ways, but simply imaging yourself well does not work. You do seem to have figured out how to replenish your blood, however, which is useful."

pɛɹɪn smɛl sʌmθɪŋ. tɛɹɝ. wɑz ɪɾ ɪz oʊn?

Perrin smelled something. Terror. Was it his own?

No. No, there. Behind Slayer was a doorway open into the White Tower Inside was blackness.

"ɛksələnt," mɛsænə sɛd. "sʌtʃ ənɹuli tʃɪlʒɹən jə ɑɹ." ʃi klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn dɪsəpɹuvəl.

"Excellent," Mesaana said. "Such unruly children you are." She clicked her tongue in disapproval.

ɪn ə moʊmənt, ʃi ʃɪftəd sʌmwɛɹ ɛls, teɪkɪŋ ɛɡwin wɪð hɝ. ə tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð noʊ wɪndoʊz, lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ kʌt dɝɛkli fɹəm stoʊn. ðəɹ wɑzn ivən ə dɔɹweɪ.

In a moment, she shifted somewhere else, taking Egwene with her. A chamber with no windows, looking as if it were cut directly from stone. There wasn't even a doorway.

ɑlviɛɝɪn weɪɾəd hɪɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs ʌv waɪɾ ən ɹɛd. ðə wʊmən ɪmiɾiətli nɛl bɪfɔɹ mɛsænə, ðoʊ ʃi spɛɹɾ ə sæɾəsfaɪd ɡlæns fəɹ ɛɡwin.

Alviarin waited here, wearing a dress of white and red. The woman immediately knelt before Mesaana, though she spared a satisfied glance for Egwene.

ɛɡwin bɛɹli noʊɾəst. ʃi stʊd, stɪf, ə taɪɾ ə pænɪk θɔts flʌɾɪŋ əɹ maɪnd. ʃi wɑz tʃɹæpt əɡɛn! ʃi kəd nɑt stæn ɪt. ʃi wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi əlaʊd ðɪs tə hæpən. ɪmədʒəz flæʃt ɪn əɹ hɛd. tʃɹæpt ɪn ə ɹum, əneɪbəl tə muv mɔɹ ðən ə fju fit wɪθaʊt biɪŋ oʊvɝkʌm baɪ ði æɾəm. tʃɹiɾəd laɪk ən ænəməl, ə kɹipɪŋ sɛns ðət ʃi wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɹeɪk, wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɪkʌm ɪɡzækli wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəɾ əɹ tə bi.

Egwene barely noticed. She stood, stiff, a tide of panicked thoughts flooding her mind. She was trapped again! She could not stand it. She would die before she allowed this to happen. Images flashed in her head. Trapped in a room, unable to move more than a few feet without being overcome by the a'dam. Treated like an animal, a creeping sense that she would eventually break, would eventually become exactly what they wanted her to be.

oʊ, laɪt. ʃi kəd nɑt sʌfɝ ðɪs əɡɛn. nɑt ðɪs.

Oh, Light. She could not suffer this again. Not this.

"tɛl ðoʊz əbʌv tə wɪðdʒɹɔ," mɛsænə wɑz seɪɪŋ tə ɑlviɛɝɪn, hɝ vɔɪs kɑm. ɛɡwin bɛɹli ɹɛdʒəstɝd ðə wɝdz. "fulz ðeɪ ɑɹ, ən ðɛɹ ʃoʊɪŋ hɪɹ wɑz pəθɛɾɪk. pʌnɪʃməns wɪl bi ədmɪnəstɝd."

"Tell those above to withdraw," Mesaana was saying to Alviarin, her voice calm. Egwene barely registered the words. "Fools they are, and their showing here was pathetic. Punishments will be administered."

ðɪs wɑz haʊ mɑɡiɾin hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd baɪ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. ʃi wɑz kɛp kæptɪv, fɔɹs tə də əz ðeɪ dɪmændəd. ɛɡwin wəd sʌfɝ ðə seɪm! ɪndid, mɛsænə wəd pɹɑbli juz kəmpʌlʃən ɑn hɝ. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd bi fʊli ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

This was how Moghedien had been captured by Nynaeve and Elayne. She was kept captive, forced to do as they demanded. Egwene would suffer the same! Indeed, Mesaana would probably use Compulsion on her. The White Tower would be fully in the hands of the Forsaken.

ði ɪmoʊʃənz wɛld ʌp. ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf klɔɪŋ ət ðə kɑlɝ, wɪtʃ ɡɑɾ ə lʊk ʌv əmjuzmən fɹəm mɛsænə əz ɑlviɛɝɪn vænɪʃt tə ɹileɪ hɝ ɔɹɾɝ.

The emotions welled up. Egwene found herself clawing at the collar, which got a look of amusement from Mesaana as Alviarin vanished to relay her order.

ðɪs kəd nɑt bi hæpənɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə naɪtmɛɹ. ə -  jə ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə kwaɪət pis ə hɝ wɪspɝd ðə wɝdz, jɛt fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ sɔfnəs, ðeɪ wɝ stʃɹɔŋ. ən ðeɪ wɝ dip wɪðɪn hɝ. ðə vɔɪs wɑz dipɝ ðən ðə tɛɹɝ ən fɪɹ.

This could not be happening. It was a nightmare. A -  You are Aes Sedai. A quiet piece of her whispered the words, yet for all their softness, they were strong. And they were deep within her. The voice was deeper than the terror and fear.

"naʊ," mɛsænə sɛd. "wi wɪl spik ə ðə dʒɹimspaɪk. wɛɹ maɪɾ aɪ faɪn ɪt?"

"Now," Mesaana said. "We will speak of the dreamspike. Where might I find it?"

ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz kɑmnəs, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz kəntʃɹoʊl, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən. ɛɡwin loʊɝɾ əɹ hænz fɹəm ðə kɑlɝ. ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɔn θɹu ðə tɛstɪŋ, ən ʃi hæd nɑt plæn tə. bʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd, wʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə feɪs ə sɪtʃueɪʃən laɪk ðɪs? wəd ʃi hæv bɹoʊkən? pɹuvən hɝsɛlf ənwɝði ʌv ðə mæntəl ʃi kleɪm tə kæɹi?

An Aes Sedai is calmness, an Aes Sedai is control, regardless of the situation. Egwene lowered her hands from the collar. She had not gone through the testing, and she had not planned to. But if she had, what if she had been forced to face a situation like this? Would she have broken? Proven herself unworthy of the mantle she claimed to carry?

"nɑt spikɪŋ, aɪ si," mɛsænə sɛd. "wɛl, ðət kən bi tʃeɪnʒd. ðiz æɾəm. sətʃ lʌvli dɪvaɪsəz. sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz soʊ dɪlaɪtfəli wʌndɝfəl ɪn bɹɪŋɪŋ əm tə maɪ ətɛnʃən, ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd soʊ æksədɛntəli. pɪɾi ʃi daɪd bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəd pleɪs wʌn ɑn əɹ nɛk."

"Not speaking, I see," Mesaana said. "Well, that can be changed. These a'dam. Such lovely devices. Semirhage was so delightfully wonderful in bringing them to my attention, even if she did so accidentally. Pity she died before I could place one on her neck."

peɪn ʃɑt θɹu ɛɡwinz bɑɾi, laɪk faɪɝ bɪniθ əɹ skɪn. hɝ aɪz wɔɾɝd fɹəm ɪt.

Pain shot through Egwene's body, like fire beneath her skin. Her eyes watered from it.

bʌt ʃi hæd sʌfɝd peɪn bɪfɔɹ, ən læft waɪl biɪŋ biɾən. ʃi hæd bɪn kæptɪv bɪfɔɹ, ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf, ən kæptɪvəɾi hæd nɑt stɑp hɝ.

But she had suffered pain before, and laughed while being beaten. She had been captive before, in the White Tower itself, and captivity had not stopped her.

bʌt ðɪs ɪz dɪfɹənt! ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɑz tɛɹəfaɪd. ðɪs ɪz ði æɾəm! aɪ kænɑt wɪθstæn ɪt!

But this is different! The larger part of her was terrified. This is the a'dam! I cannot withstand it!

ən ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌst, ðə kwaɪət pis ə hɝ ɹɪplaɪd. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kən sʌfɝ ɔl θɪŋz, fəɹ oʊnli ðən kən ʃi bi tʃɹuli ə sɝvən ʌv ɔl.

An Aes Sedai must, the quiet piece of her replied. An Aes Sedai can suffer all things, for only then can she be truly a servant of all.

"naʊ," mɛsænə sɛd. "tɛl mi wɛɹ juv hɪɾən ðə dɪvaɪs."

"Now," Mesaana said. "Tell me where you have hidden the device."

ɛɡwin kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ fɪɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd! bʌt ʃi dɪɾ ɪt. hɝ feɪs bɪkeɪm kɑm. ʃi dɪfaɪd ði æɾəm baɪ nɑt ɡɪvɪŋ ɪt paʊɝ oʊvɝ hɝ.

Egwene controlled her fear. It was not easy. Light, but it was hard! But she did it. Her face became calm. She defied the a'dam by not giving it power over her.

mɛsænə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ʃi ʃʊk ðə liʃ, ən mɔɹ peɪn flʌɾəd ɛɡwin.

Mesaana hesitated, frowning. She shook the leash, and more pain flooded Egwene.

ʃi meɪɾ ɪt vænɪʃ. "ɪɾ əkɝz tə mi, mɛsænə," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli, "ðæt mɑɡiɾin meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. ʃi æksɛptɪd ði æɾəm!'

She made it vanish. "It occurs to me, Mesaana," Egwene said calmly, "that Moghedien made a mistake. She accepted the a'dam!'

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə - "

"What are you - "

"ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, ən æɾəm ɪz əz minɪŋləs əz ðə wivz ɪt pɹɪvɛns," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz oʊnli ə pis ə mɛɾəl. ən ɪɾ oʊnli wɪl stɑp jə ɪf jə æksɛp ðəɾ ɪt wɪl." ði æɾəm ənlɑkt ən fɛl fɹi ʌv əɹ nɛk.

"In this place, an a'dam is as meaningless as the weaves it prevents," Egwene said. "It is only a piece of metal. And it only will stop you if you accept that it will." The a'dam unlocked and fell free of her neck.

mɛsænə ɡlænst əɾ ɪɾ əz ɪt dʒɹɑp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ə mətælɪk ɹɪŋ. hɝ feɪs ɡɹu stɪl, ðən koʊld əz ʃi lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɛɡwin. ɪmpɹɛsɪvli, ʃi dɪd nɑt pænɪk. ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, aɪz ɪmpæsɪv. "soʊ, juv pɹæktəs hɪɹ."

Mesaana glanced at it as it dropped to the ground with a metallic ring. Her face grew still, then cold as she looked up at Egwene. Impressively, she did not panic. She folded her arms, eyes impassive. "So, you have practiced here."

ɛɡwin mɛɾ əɹ ɡeɪz.

Egwene met her gaze.

jə ɑɹ stɪl ə tʃaɪld," mɛsænə sɛd. "ju θɪŋk ðət jə kən bɛs mi? hæv wɔkt ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd lɔŋɡɝ ðən jə kən ɪmædʒən. jə ɑɹ wʌt, twɛnti jɪɹz oʊld?"

You are still a child," Mesaana said. "You think that you can best me? have walked in Tel'aran'rhiod longer than you can imagine. You are what, twenty years old?"

aɪm ði æmɪɝlɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn æmɪɝlɪn tə tʃɪlʒɹən."

I am the Amyrlin," Egwene said. "An Amyrlin to children."

ən æmɪɝlɪn tə ə taʊɝ ðəɾ əz stʊd fəɹ θaʊzənz ə jɪɹz," ɛɡwin sɛd. θaʊzənz ə jɪɹz ə tʃɹʌbəl ən keɪɑs. jɛt moʊst ə jəɹ laɪf, jə lɪvd ɪn ə taɪm ə pis, nɑt stʃɹaɪf. kjʊɹiəs, ðət jə ʃəd θɪŋk jɝsɛlf soʊ stʃɹɔŋ wən mʌtʃ ə jəɹ laɪf wɑz soʊ izi."

An Amyrlin to a Tower that has stood for thousands of years," Egwene said. Thousands of years of trouble and chaos. Yet most of your life, you lived in a time of peace, not strife. Curious, that you should think yourself so strong when much of your life was so easy."

"izi?" mɛsænə sɛd. "ju noʊ nʌθɪŋ."

"Easy?" Mesaana said. "You know nothing."

niðɝ bɹoʊk əɹ ɡeɪz. ɛɡwin fɛl sʌmθɪŋ pɹɛs əɡɛnst əɹ əz ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ. mɛsænəz wɪl, dɪmændɪŋ əɹ səbsɝviəns, hɝ sʌpləkeɪʃən. ən ətɛmp tə juz tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə vɛɹi weɪ ðəɾ ɛɡwin θɔt.

Neither broke her gaze. Egwene felt something press against her as it had before. Mesaana's will, demanding her subservience, her supplication. An attempt to use Tel'aran'rhiod to change the very way that Egwene thought.

mɛsænə wɑz stʃɹɔŋ. bʌt stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs wɑz ə mæɾɝ ə pɝ-. spɛktɪv. mɛsænəz wɪl pɹɛst əɡɛns hɝ. bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd dɪfiɾəd ði æɾəm. ʃi kəd ɹɪzɪs ðɪs.

Mesaana was strong. But strength in this place was a matter of per-. spective. Mesaana's will pressed against her. But Egwene had defeated the a'dam. She could resist this.

"ju wɪl bɛnd," mɛsænə sɛd kwaɪətli.

"You will bend," Mesaana said quietly.

"ju ɑɹ mɪsteɪkən," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd, vɔɪs tɛns. "ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ əbaʊt mi ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ ɪz ə tʃaɪld. bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz nɑt. aɪ meɪ bi jʌŋ, bʌt ðə siɾ ɪz eɪntʃənt."

"You are mistaken," Egwene replied, voice tense. "This is not about me Egwene al'Vere is a child. But the Amyrlin is not. I may be young, but the Seat is ancient."

niðɝ wʊmən lʊkt əweɪ. ɛɡwin bɪɡæn tə pʊʃ bæk, tə dɪmæn ðət mɛsænə baʊ bɪfɔɹ hɝ, bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn. ði ɛɹ bɪɡæn tə fil hɛvi ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən wən ɛɡwin bɹiðd ɪɾ ɪn, ɪt sim θɪk sʌmhaʊ.

Neither woman looked away. Egwene began to push back, to demand that Mesaana bow before her, before the Amyrlin. The air began to feel heavy around them, and when Egwene breathed it in, it seemed thick somehow.

"eɪdʒ ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "tə ən ɪkstɛnt, ivən ɪkspɪɹiəns ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt. ðɪs pleɪs ɪz əbaʊt wʌɾ ə pɝsən ɪz. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪl nɑt bɛnd. ɪt dɪfaɪz ju, mɛsænə, ən jəɹ laɪz."

"Age is irrelevant," Egwene said. "To an extent, even experience is irrelevant. This place is about what a person is. The Amyrlin is the White Tower, and the White Tower will not bend. It defies you, Mesaana, and your lies."

tu wɪmən. ɡeɪzəz mætʃt. ɛɡwin stɑp bɹiðɪŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt nid tə bɹið. ɔl wɑz foʊkəst ɑn mɛsænə. swɛt tʃɹɪkəl daʊn ɛɡwnz tɛmpəlz, ɛvɹi mʌsəl ɪn əɹ bɑɾi tɛns əz ʃi pʊʃt bæk əɡɛns mɛsænəz wɪl.

Two women. Gazes matched. Egwene stopped breathing. She did not need to breathe. All was focused on Mesaana. Sweat trickled down Egwenes temples, every muscle in her body tense as she pushed back against Mesaana's will.

ən ɛɡwin nu ðət ðɪs wʊmən, ðɪs kɹitʃɝ, wɑz ən ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkən ɪnsɛkt ʃʌvɪŋ əɡɛnst ən ɪnɔɹməs maʊntən. ðət maʊntən wəd nɑt muv. ɪndid, ʃʌv əɡɛnst ɪt tu hɑɹd, ən . . .

And Egwene knew that this woman, this creature, was an insignificant insect shoving against an enormous mountain. That mountain would not move. Indeed, shove against it too hard, and . . .

sʌmθɪŋ snæpt, sɔfli, ɪn ðə ɹum.

Something snapped, softly, in the room.

ɛɡwin bɹiðd ɪn wɪð ə ɡæsp əz ði ɛɹ ɹɪtɝn tə nɔɹməl. mɛsænə dʒɹɑp laɪk ə dɑl meɪɾ ə stʃɹɪps ə klɔθ. ʃi hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð əɹ aɪz stɪl oʊpən, ən ə lɪɾəl bɪɾ ə spɪɾəl dʒɹɪbəl fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ maʊθ.

Egwene breathed in with a gasp as the air returned to normal. Mesaana dropped like a doll made of strips of cloth. She hit the ground with her eyes still open, and a little bit of spittle dribbled from the corner of her mouth.

ɛɡwin sæt daʊn, deɪzd, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ ɪn ɡæsps. ʃi lʊk tə ðə saɪd, wɛɹ ði æɾəm leɪ dɪskɑɹɾɪd. ɪt vænɪʃt. ðən ʃi lʊk bæk ət mɛsænə, hu leɪ ɪn ə hip. hɝ tʃɛst wɑz stɪl ɹaɪzɪŋ ən loʊɝɪŋ, bʌt ʃi stɛɹd wɪð saɪtləs aɪz.

Egwene sat down, dazed, breathing in and out in gasps. She looked to the side, where the a'dam lay discarded. It vanished. Then she looked back at Mesaana, who lay in a heap. Her chest was still rising and lowering, but she stared with sightless eyes.

ɛɡwin leɪ fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ bɪfɔɹ stændɪŋ ən ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs. ʃi woʊv laɪnz ʌv ɛɹ tə lɪf ði ʌnɹispɑnsɪv fɔɹseɪkən, ðən ʃɪftəd boʊθ hɝsɛlf ən ðə wʊmən bæk tə ði ʌpɝ flɔɹz ə ðə taʊɝ.

Egwene lay for a long moment recovering before standing and embracing the Source. She wove lines of Air to lift the unresponsive Forsaken, then shifted both herself and the woman back to the upper floors of the Tower.

wɪmən tɝn təwɔɹɾ əɹ wɪð ə stɑɹt. ðə hɔlweɪ hɪɹ wɑz stʃɹun wɪð ɹʌbəl, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛɡwin sɔ wɑz wʌn ə hɝz. ðə waɪz wʌnz, spɪnɪŋ ɑn hɝ.

Women turned toward her with a start. The hallway here was strewn with rubble, but everyone Egwene saw was one of hers. The Wise Ones, spinning on her.

nɪneɪiv pɪkɪŋ θɹu səm ɹʌbəl. sɪuən ən lin, ðə læɾɝ bɛɹɪŋ sɛvɹəl blækən kʌts ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌt lʊkɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ. "mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd wɪð ɹɪlif. "wi hæd fɪɹd . . ." "hu ɪz ðæt?"

Nynaeve picking through some rubble. Siuan and Leane, the latter bearing several blackened cuts on her face, but looking strong. "Mother," Siuan said with relief. "We had feared . . ." "Who is that?"

məleɪn æskt, wɔkɪŋ ʌp tə mɛsænə, hæŋɪŋ lɪmpli ɪn ðə wivz ʌv ɛɹ ən stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Melaine asked, walking up to Mesaana, hanging limply in the weaves of Air and staring at the ground.

ðə wʊmən koʊud sʌɾənli, laɪk ə tʃaɪld, aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ ə bɪɾ ə bɝnɪŋ faɪɝ ɑn ðə ɹɛmnəns ʌv ə tæpəstʃɹi.

The woman cooed suddenly, like a child, eyes watching a bit of burning fire on the remnants of a tapestry.

"ɪɾ ɪz hɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, taɪɝd. "mɛsænə."

"It is her," Egwene said, tired. "Mesaana."

məleɪn tɝn tə ɛɡwin, aɪz waɪd wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

Melaine turned to Egwene, eyes wide with surprise.

"laɪt!" lin ɪkskleɪmd. "wʌɾ əv jə dʌn?"

"Light!" Leane exclaimed. "What have you done?"

"aɪ hæv sin ðɪs bɪfɔɹ," bɛɹ sɛd, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə wʊmən. "sɑmænə, ə waɪz wʌn dʒɹimɝ fɹəm maɪ juθ. ʃi ɪnkaʊntɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə dʒɹim ðət bɹoʊk əɹ maɪnd." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ʃi spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ deɪz ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝl dʒɹulɪŋ, ən niɾɪŋ əɹ lɪnən tʃeɪnʒd. ʃi nɛvɝ spoʊk əɡɛn, ət lis nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ðə wɝdz ʌv ə beɪb u kən bɛɹli wɔk."

"I have seen this before," Bair said, inspecting the woman. "Sammana, a Wise One Dreamer from my youth. She encountered something in the dream that broke her mind." She hesitated. "She spent the rest of her days in the waking world drooling, and needing her linen changed. She never spoke again, at least nothing more than the words of a babe who can barely walk."

"pɝhæps ɪts taɪm tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ ə jə əz ən əpɹɛntəs, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," æmɪz sɛd.

"Perhaps it is time to stop thinking of you as an apprentice, Egwene al'Vere," Amys said.

nɪneɪiv stʊd wɪð hænz ɑn hɪps, lʊkɪŋ ɪmpɹɛs bʌt stɪl klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹs. hɝ bɹeɪd wɑz fʊl lɛŋθ əɡɛn ɪn ðə dʒɹim. "ði ʌðɝz əv ɡɔn," ʃi sɛd.

Nynaeve stood with hands on hips, looking impressed but still clinging to the Source. Her braid was full length again in the dream. "The others have gone," she said.

"mɛsænə ɔɹɾɝd əm tə fli," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Mesaana ordered them to flee," Egwene said.

"ðeɪ kʊdn əv ɡɔn fɑɹ," sɪuən sɛd. "ðæt doʊm ɪz stɪl ðɛɹ."

"They couldn't have gone far," Siuan said. "That dome is still there."

"jɛs," bɛɹ sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪts taɪm fəɹ ðɪs bæɾəl tə ɛnd. ði ɛnəmi hæz bɪn dɪfiɾəd. wɪl spik əɡɛn, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ."

"Yes," Bair said. "But it is time for this battle to end. The enemy has been defeated. We will speak again, Egwene al'Vere."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. "aɪ əɡɹi ɑn boʊθ pɔɪns. bɛɹ, æmɪz, məleɪn, θæŋk jə fəɹ jəɹ mʌtʃ-niɾəd eɪd. juv ɡeɪn mʌtʃ dʒi ɪn ðɪs, ən aɪm ɪn jəɹ dɛt."

Egwene nodded. "I agree on both points. Bair, Amys, Melaine, thank you for your much-needed aid. You have gained much ji in this, and I am in your debt."

məleɪn aɪd ðə fɔɹseɪkən əz ɛɡwin sɛn hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹim. "aɪ bɪliv ɪts ʌs, ən ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf, hu ɑɹ ɪn jəɹ dɛt, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ."

Melaine eyed the Forsaken as Egwene sent herself out of the dream. "I believe it is us, and the world itself, who are in your debt, Egwene al'Vere."

ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd, ən əz ɛɡwin feɪɾəd fɹəm tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ʃi hɝd bɛɹ mʌɾɝɪŋ, "sʌtʃ ə ʃeɪm ʃi dɪdn ɹɪtɝn tə ʌs."

The others nodded, and as Egwene faded from Tel'aran'rhiod, she heard Bair muttering, "Such a shame she didn't return to us."

'pɛɹɪn ɹæn θɹu kɹaʊdz ə tɛɹəfaɪd pipəl, ɪn ə bɝnɪŋ sɪɾi. tɑɹ vəlɑn. əfleɪm! ðə vɛɹi stoʊnz bɝnd, ðə skaɪ ə dip ɹɛd. ðə ɡɹaʊn tʃɹɛmbəld, laɪk ə wundəd bʌk kɪkɪŋ əz ə lɛpɝd blɛɾ ɪts nɛk. pɛɹɪn stʌmbəld əz ə kæzəm oʊpən bɪfɔɹ hɪm, fleɪmz bleɪzɪŋ ʌpwɝd, sɪŋɡɪŋ ðə hɛɹz ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz.

'Perrin ran through crowds of terrified people, in a burning city. Tar Valon. Aflame! The very stones burned, the sky a deep red. The ground trembled, like a wounded buck kicking as a leopard bled its neck. Perrin stumbled as a chasm opened before him, flames blazing upward, singeing the hairs on his arms.

pipəl skɹimd əz səm fɛl ɪndə ðə tɛɹəbəl ɹɪft, bɝnɪŋ əweɪ ɪndə nʌθɪŋ. bɑɾiz sʌɾənli lɪɾɝd ðə ɡɹaʊnd. tə hɪz ɹaɪt, ə bjuɾəfəl bɪldɪŋ wɪð ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz bɪɡæn tə mɛlt, ðə ɹɑk tɝnɪŋ lɪkwəd, lɑvə bliɾɪŋ fɹəm bɪtwin stoʊnz ən aʊɾ ʌv oʊpənɪŋz.

People screamed as some fell into the terrible rift, burning away into nothing. Bodies suddenly littered the ground. To his right, a beautiful building with arched windows began to melt, the rock turning liquid, lava bleeding from between stones and out of openings.

pɛɹɪn klaɪm tə hɪz fit. ɪts nɑt ɹil.

Perrin climbed to his feet. It's not real.

"tɑɹmən ɡdən!" pipəl jɛld. "ðə læs bæɾəl əz kʌm! ɪɾ ɛnz! laɪt, ɪɾ ɛnz!"

"Tarmon Gai'don!" people yelled. "The Last Battle has come! It ends! Light, it ends!"

pɛɹɪn stʌmbəld, pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp əɡɛnst ə tʃʌŋk ə ɹɑk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stænd. hɪz ɑɹm hɝt, ən ɪz fɪŋɡɝz wʊdnt ɡɹɪp, bʌt ðə wɝst waʊnd wɑz ɪn ɪz lɛɡ, wɛɹ ði æɹoʊ hæd hɪt. hɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz ən koʊt wɝ wɛt wɪð blʌd, ən ðə sɛn ə hɪz oʊn tɛɹɝ wɑz paʊɝfəl ɪn ɪz noʊz.

Perrin stumbled, pulling himself up against a chunk of rock, trying to stand. His arm hurt, and his fingers wouldn't grip, but the worst wound was in his leg, where the arrow had hit. His trousers and coat were wet with blood, and the scent of his own terror was powerful in his nose.

hi nu ðɪs naɪtmɛɹ wɑz nɑt ɹil. ən jɛt, haʊ kəd wʌn nɑt fil ðə hɔɹɝ ʌv ɪt? tə ðə wɛst, dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt wɑz ɪɹʌptɪŋ, plumz ʌv æŋɡɹi smoʊk bɪloʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə skaɪ. ði ɪntaɪɝ maʊntən simd əfleɪm, ɹɪvɝz ə ɹɛd sɝdʒɪŋ daʊn ɪts saɪdz. pɛɹɪn kəd fil ɪt ʃeɪkɪŋ, daɪɪŋ. bɪldɪŋz kɹækt, tʃɹɛmbəld, mɛltəd, ʃæɾɝd. pipəl daɪd, kɹʌʃt baɪ stoʊnz əɹ bɝn tə dɛθ.

He knew this nightmare was not real. And yet, how could one not feel the horror of it? To the west, Dragonmount was erupting, plumes of angry smoke billowing into the sky. The entire mountain seemed aflame, rivers of red surging down its sides. Perrin could feel it shaking, dying. Buildings cracked, trembled, melted, shattered. People died, crushed by stones or burned to death.

noʊ. hi wəd nɑt bi dʒɹɔn ɪn. ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn ɪm tʃeɪnʒd fɹəm bɹoʊkən kɑbəlz tə nit taɪlz;

No. He would not be drawn in. The ground around him changed from broken cobbles to neat tiles;

ðə sɝvəns' ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. pɛɹɪn fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə stæf tə juz ɪn lɪmpɪŋ.

the servants' entrance to the White Tower. Perrin forced himself to his feet, creating a staff to use in limping.

hi dɪdn dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə naɪtmɛɹ; hi hæd tə faɪn sleɪɝ. ɪn ðɪs tɛɹəbəl pleɪs, pɛɹɪn maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɡeɪn ən ædvæntɪdʒ. sleɪɝ wɑz vɛɹi pɹæktəst ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, bʌt pɝhæps - ɪf pɛɹɪn hæd lʌk ɑn ɪz saɪd - ðə mæn wɑz skɪld ɪnʌf tə hæv əvɔɪɾəd naɪtmɛɹz ɪn ðə pæst. pɝhæps i wəd bi stɑɹɾəld baɪ ðɪs wʌn, teɪkən ɪn.

He didn't destroy the nightmare; he had to find Slayer. In this terrible place, Perrin might be able to gain an advantage. Slayer was very practiced in Tel'aran'rhiod, but perhaps - if Perrin had luck on his side - the man was skilled enough to have avoided nightmares in the past. Perhaps he would be startled by this one, taken in.

ɹɪlʌktənli, pɛɹɪn wikən ɪz ɹizɑlv, lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bi dʒɹɔn ɪndə ðə naɪtmɛɹ. sleɪɝ wəd bi kloʊs. pɛɹɪn stʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, steɪɪŋ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə bɪldɪŋ wɪð ðə lɑvə bɔɪlɪŋ fɹəm ɪts wɪndoʊz. ɪf wɑz hɑɹd tə kip hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ɡɪvɪŋ ɪn tə ðə skɹimz ə hɔɹɝ ən peɪn. ðə kɔlz fəɹ hɛlp.

Reluctantly, Perrin weakened his resolve, letting himself be drawn into the nightmare. Slayer would be close. Perrin stumbled across the street, staying far from the building with the lava boiling from its windows. If was hard to keep himself from giving in to the screams of horror and pain. The calls for help.

ðɛɹ, pɛɹɪn θɔt, ɹitʃɪŋ ən æli. sleɪɝ stʊɾ ɪnsaɪd, hɛd baʊd, ə hæn ʌp əɡɛnst wʌn wɔl. ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd ðə mæn ɛndəɾ ɪn ə ɹɪft, bɔɪlɪŋ mæɡmə ət ðə bɑɾəm. pipəl klʌŋ tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡæp,, skɹimɪŋ. sleɪɝ ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. wɛɹ ɪz hæn tʌtʃt ðə wɔl, ɪt stɑɹɾəd tə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm waɪtwɑʃt bɹɪk tə ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ə ðə waɪt taʊɝz ɪntɪɹiɝ.

There, Perrin thought, reaching an alley. Slayer stood inside, head bowed, a hand up against one wall. The ground beside the man ended in a rift, boiling magma at the bottom. People clung to the edge of the gap,, screaming. Slayer ignored them. Where his hand touched the wall, it started to change from whitewashed brick to the gray stone of the White Tower's interior.

ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil stɪl hʌŋ ət sleɪɝz weɪst. pɛɹɪn hæd tə muv kwɪkli- ðə wɔl ɪz mɛltɪŋ fɹəm ðə hit, pɛɹɪn θɔt, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔl bɪsaɪd sleɪɝ. ɪt wɑz iziɝ, hɪɹ, tə tʃeɪnʒ θɪŋz laɪk ðət - ɪt wɑz pleɪɪŋ ɪndə ðə wɝl ðə naɪtmɛɹ kɹieɪɾəd.

The ter'angreal still hung at Slayer's waist. Perrin had to move quickly- The wall is melting from the heat, Perrin thought, focusing on the wall beside Slayer. It was easier, here, to change things like that - it was playing into the world the nightmare created.

sleɪɝ kɝst, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæn bæk əz ðə wɔl ɡɹu ɹɛd-hɑt. ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ ɪm ɹʌmbəld, ən ɪz aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾ ɪn əlɑɹm. hi spʌn əz ə ɹɪft oʊpən bɪsaɪd hɪm, pɹədʒɛktəd ðəɹ baɪ pɛɹɪn. ɪn ðət moʊmənt, pɛɹɪn sɔ ðət sleɪɝ bɪlivd - fəɹ dʒʌst ə fɹækʃən ʌv ə sɛkʃən - ðət ðə naɪtmɛɹ wɑz ɹil. sleɪɝ stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪft, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn əɡɛnst ɪts hit, bɪlivɪŋ ɪt ɹil.

Slayer cursed, pulling his hand back as the wall grew red-hot. The ground beneath him rumbled, and his eyes opened wide in alarm. He spun as a rift opened beside him, projected there by Perrin. In that moment, Perrin saw that Slayer believed - for just a fraction of a section - that the nightmare was real. Slayer stepped away from the rift, raising a hand against its heat, believing it real.

sleɪɝ vænɪʃt ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ, əpɪɹɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðoʊz hæŋɪŋ əbʌv ðə ɹɪft. ðə naɪtmɛɹ ɪnkɔɹpɝeɪɾəd hɪm, sʌkɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ɪts wɪmz, meɪkɪŋ ɪm pleɪ ə ɹoʊl ɪn ɪts tɛɹɝz. ɪt nɪɹli tʊk pɛɹɪn, tu. hi fɛl hɪmsɛlf weɪvɝ, nɪɹli ɹɪspɑndɪŋ tə ðə hit. bʌt noʊ. hɑpɝ wɑz daɪɪŋ. hi wəd nɑt feɪl!

Slayer vanished in the blink of an eye, appearing beside those hanging above the rift. The nightmare incorporated him, sucking him into its whims, making him play a role in its terrors. It nearly took Perrin, too. He felt himself waver, nearly responding to the heat. But no. Hopper was dying. He would not fail!

pɛɹɪn ɪmædʒən hɪmsɛlf əz sʌmwʌn ɛls. ɑzi ælθoʊn, wʌn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. pɛɹɪn pʊt hɪmsɛlf ɪn kloʊðɪŋ laɪk ðət hid sin ɑn ðə stʃɹit, ə vɛst ən ə waɪt ʃɝt, faɪnɝ tʃɹaʊzɝz ðən ɛni mæn wəd wɛɹ waɪl wɝkɪŋ ɪn ɛmənz fild. ðɪs stɛp wɑz ɔlmoʊs tu mʌtʃ fəɹ hɪm. hɪz hɑɹt bit fæstɝ, ən i stʌmbəld əz ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹʌmbəld. ɪf i lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi kɑɾ ʌp kəmplitli ɪn ðə naɪtmɛɹ, hiɾ ɛn ʌp laɪk sleɪɝ.

Perrin imagined himself as someone else. Azi al'Thone, one of the Two Rivers men. Perrin put himself in clothing like that he'd seen on the street, a vest and a white shirt, finer trousers than any man would wear while working in Emond's Field. This step was almost too much for him. His heart beat faster, and he stumbled as the ground rumbled. If he let himself be caught up completely in the nightmare, he'd end up like Slayer.

noʊ, pɛɹɪn θɔt, fɔɹsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə hoʊl tə hɪz mɛmɹi ʌv feɪl ɪn ɪz hɑɹt. hɪz hoʊm. hɪz feɪs maɪt tʃeɪnʒ, ðə wɝl maɪt ʃeɪk, bʌt ðət wɑz stɪl hoʊm.

No, Perrin thought, forcing himself to hold to his memory of Faile in his heart. His home. His face might change, the world might shake, but that was still home.

hi ɹæn tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹɪft, əbʌv ðə hit, æktɪŋ əz ɪf i wɝ dʒʌst ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə naɪtmɛɹ. hi skɹimd ɪn tɛɹɝ, ɹitʃɪŋ daʊn tə hɛlp ðoʊz u wɝ fɔlɪŋ. ðoʊ hi ɹitʃt fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls, sleɪɝ kɝst ən ɡɹæbd ɪz ɑɹm, juzɪŋ ɪt tə hiv hɪmsɛlf ʌpwɝd.

He ran to the edge of the rift, above the heat, acting as if he were just another part of the nightmare. He screamed in terror, reaching down to help those who were falling. Though he reached for someone else, Slayer cursed and grabbed his arm, using it to heave himself upward.

ən əz i pæst, pɛɹɪn ɡɹæb ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. sleɪɝ kɹɔld oʊvɝ hɪm, ɹitʃɪŋ ðə ɹɛləɾɪv seɪfti ʌv ði æli. kʌvɝtli, pɛɹɪn meɪɾ ə naɪf ɪn ɪz ʌðɝ hænd.

And as he passed, Perrin grabbed the ter'angreal. Slayer crawled over him, reaching the relative safety of the alley. Covertly, Perrin made a knife in his other hand.

'bɝn mi," sleɪɝ ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ heɪt ðiz θɪŋz." ði ɛɹiə ɝaʊn əm sʌɾənli tʃeɪnʒd tə taɪlz.

'Burn me," Slayer growled. "I hate these things." The area around them suddenly changed to tiles.

pɛɹɪn stʊɾ ʌp, hoʊldɪŋ ə stæf tə stɛɾi hɪmsɛlf ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əpɪɹ tɛɹəfaɪd - ɪt wɑzn hɑɹd. hi bɪɡæn tə stʌmbəl pæst sleɪɝ. ɪn ðət moʊ-mɛnt, ðə hɑɹd-feɪs mæn lʊk daʊn ən sɔ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn pɛɹɪnz æŋɡɝz.

Perrin stood up, holding a staff to steady himself and trying to appear terrified - it wasn't hard. He began to stumble past Slayer. In that mo-ment, the hard-faced man looked down and saw the ter'angreal in Perrin's Angers.

hɪz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd. pɛɹɪn ɹæmd ɪz hæn fɔɹwɝd, plʌnʒɪŋ ðə naɪf ɪndə sleɪɝz stʌmək.

His eyes opened wide. Perrin rammed his hand forward, plunging the knife into Slayer's stomach.

ðə mæn skɹimd, lɝtʃɪŋ bækwɝd, hæn tə hɪz bɛli. blʌd soʊkt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz.

The man screamed, lurching backward, hand to his belly. Blood soaked his fingers.

sleɪɝ klɛntʃt ɪz tiθ. ðə naɪtmɛɹ bɛn ɝaʊn hɪm. ɪt wəd bɝst sun. sleɪɝ ɹaɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz blʌɾid hænd, aɪz əlaɪt wɪð æŋɡɝ.

Slayer clenched his teeth. The nightmare bent around him. It would burst soon. Slayer righted himself, lowering his bloodied hand, eyes alight with anger.

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ənstɛɾi ɑn ɪz fit, ivən wɪð ðə stæf. hid bɪn wundəd soʊ bædli. ðə ɡɹaʊn tʃɹɛmbəld. ə ɹɪft oʊpən ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd nɛks tə hɪm, stimɪŋ wɪð hiɾ ən lɑvə, laɪk . . .

Perrin felt unsteady on his feet, even with the staff. He'd been wounded so badly. The ground trembled. A rift opened in the ground next to him, steaming with heat and lava, like . . .

pɛɹɪn stɑɹɾəd. laɪk dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. hi lʊk daʊn ət ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə fɪɹ- dʒɹimz ə pipəl ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ. hɑpɝz vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn pɛɹɪnz maɪnd. soʊ vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ. . . .

Perrin started. Like Dragonmount. He looked down at the ter'angreal in his fingers. The fear- dreams of people are strong. Hopper's voice whispered in Perrin's mind. So very strong. . . .

əz sleɪɝ ədvænst ɑn hɪm, pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ ən hɝl ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ ə lɑvə.

As Slayer advanced on him, Perrin gritted his teeth and hurled the ter'angreal into the river of lava.

"noʊ!" sleɪɝ skɹimd, ɹiæləɾi ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə naɪtmɛɹ bɝst, ɪts læs vɛstɪdʒɪz vænɪʃɪŋ. pɛɹɪn wɑz lɛf nilɪŋ ɑn ðə koʊl taɪl flɔɹ ʌv ə smɔl hɔlweɪ.

"No!" Slayer screamed, reality returning around him. The nightmare burst, its last vestiges vanishing. Perrin was left kneeling on the cold tiled floor of a small hallway.

ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns tə hɪz ɹaɪt, ə mɛltəd lʌmp ə mɛɾəl leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. pɛɹɪn smaɪld.

A short distance to his right, a melted lump of metal lay on the ground. Perrin smiled.

laɪk sleɪɝ, ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz hɪɹ fɹəm ðə ɹil wɝld. ən laɪk ə pɝsən, ɪt kəd bi bɹoʊkən ən dɪstʃɹɔɪd hɪɹ. əbʌv ðɛm, ðə vaɪəlɪt doʊm hæd vænɪʃt.

Like Slayer, the ter'angreal was here from the real world. And like a person, it could be broken and destroyed here. Above them, the violet dome had vanished.

sleɪɝ ɡɹaʊld, ðən stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən kɪk pɛɹɪn ɪn ðə stʌmək. hɪz tʃɛst waʊn flɛɹd.

Slayer growled, then stepped forward and kicked Perrin in the stomach. His chest wound flared.

ənʌðɝ kɪk fɑloʊd. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɪzi.

Another kick followed. Perrin was growing dizzy.

ɡoʊ, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt, hɪz vɔɪs soʊ wik. fli.

Go, Young Bull, Hopper sent, his voice so weak. Flee.

aɪ kæn liv ju!

I can't leave you!

ən jɛt. . . aɪ mʌs liv ju.

And yet. . . I must leave you.

noʊ!

No!

juv faʊn jəɹ ænsɝ. sik baʊnləs. hi wɪl. . . ɪkspleɪn . . . ðəɾ ænsɝ.

You have found your answer. Seek Boundless. He will. . . explain . . . that answer.

pɛɹɪn blɪŋk θɹu tɪɹz əz ənʌðɝ kɪk lændəd. hi skɹimd, ɹæədli, əz hɑpɝz sɛndɪŋ  - soʊ kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, soʊ fəmɪljɝ - feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪz maɪnd.
