Perrin blinked through tears as another kick landed. He screamed, raggedly, as Hopper's sending  - so comforting, so familiar - faded from his mind.

ɡɔn.

Gone.

pɛɹɪn skɹimd ɪn æŋɡwɪʃ. vɔɪs ɹæɡəd, aɪz steɪnd wɪð tɪɹz, pɛɹɪn wɪl hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ən əweɪ. fliɪŋ laɪk ən ʌɾɝ kaʊɝd.

Perrin screamed in anguish. Voice ragged, eyes stained with tears, Perrin willed himself out of the wolf dream and away. Fleeing like an utter coward.

ɛɡwin əwoʊk wɪð ə saɪ. aɪz stɪl kloʊzd, ʃi bɹiðd ɪn. ðə bæɾəl wɪð mɛsænə hæd lɛft əɹ maɪn filɪŋ stʃɹeɪnd - ɪndid, ʃi hæɾ ə splɪɾɪŋ hɛdeɪk. ʃi hæd kwaɪt nɪɹli bɪn dɪfiɾəd ðɛɹ. hɝ plænz hæd wɝkt, bʌt ðə weɪɾ ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən lɛft əɹ filɪŋ kəntɛmpləɾɪv, ivən ə lɪɾəl oʊvɝwɛlmd.

Egwene awoke with a sigh. Eyes still closed, she breathed in. The battle with Mesaana had left her mind feeling strained - indeed, she had a splitting headache. She had quite nearly been defeated there. Her plans had worked, but the weight of what had happened left her feeling contemplative, even a little overwhelmed.

stɪl, ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi. ʃi wəɾ əv tə də ə sɝtʃ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən faɪn ðə wʊmən hu, wən əweɪkənd, naʊ hæd ðə maɪn ʌv ə tʃaɪld. ʃi nu, sʌmhaʊ, ðət ðɪs wɑz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ mɛsænə wəd ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹʌm. ʃid noʊn ɪɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ bɛɹ hæd spoʊkən əɹ wɝdz.

Still, it had been a great victory. She would have to do a search of the White Tower and find the woman who, when awakened, now had the mind of a child. She knew, somehow, that this was not something Mesaana would recover from. She'd known it even before Bair had spoken her words.

ɛɡwin oʊpən əɹ aɪz tə ə kʌmfɝɾəbli dɑɹk ɹum, meɪkɪŋ plænz tə ɡæðɝ ðə hɔl ən ɪkspleɪn waɪ ʃɛvən ən kɑɹlɪnjə wəd nɛvɝ əweɪkən.

Egwene opened her eyes to a comfortably dark room, making plans to gather the Hall and explain why Shevan and Carlinya would never awaken.

ʃi spɛɹɾ ə moʊmən tə mɔɹn fəɹ əm əz ʃi sæɾ ʌp. ʃiɾ ɪkspleɪn tə ðɛm ðə deɪnʒɝz, bʌt stɪl ʃi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃid feɪl ðɛm. ən nɪkoʊlə, ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡoʊ fæstɝ ðən ʃi ʃʊd. ʃi ʃʊdn əv bɪn ðɛɹ. ɪt -  ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. wʌt wɑz ðət smɛl? hædnt ʃi lɛft ə læmp bɝnɪŋ? ɪt mʌst əv ɡɔn aʊt.

She spared a moment to mourn for them as she sat up. She'd explained to them the dangers, but still she felt as if she'd failed them. And Nicola, always trying to go faster than she should. She shouldn't have been there. It -  Egwene hesitated. What was that smell? Hadn't she left a lamp burning? It must have gone out.

ɛɡwin ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən woʊv ə bɔl ə laɪt tə hæŋ əbʌv əɹ hænd. ʃi wɑz stʌn baɪ ðə sin ɪt ɹɪvild.

Egwene embraced the Source and wove a ball of light to hang above her hand. She was stunned by the scene it revealed.

ðə tʃɹænslusən kɝɾənz ə hɝ bɛd hæd bɪn spɹeɪd ɹɛd wɪð blʌd, ən faɪv bɑɾiz lɪɾɝd ðə flɔɹ. θɹi wɝ ɪn blæk. wʌn wɑz ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ jʌŋ mæn ɪn ðə tɑbɝɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd. ðə læst wɔɹ ə faɪn waɪɾ ən ɹɛd koʊɾ ən tʃɹaʊzɝz.

The translucent curtains of her bed had been sprayed red with blood, and five bodies littered the floor. Three were in black. One was an unfamiliar young man in the tabard of the Tower Guard. The last wore a fine white and red coat and trousers.

ɡɔɪn!

Gawyn!

ɛɡwin θɹu hɝsɛlf fɹəm ðə bɛɾ ən nɛl bɪsaɪd hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə peɪn ə hɝ hɛdeɪk. hi wɑz bɹiðɪŋ ʃæloʊli, ən hæɾ ə ɡeɪpɪŋ waʊn ɪn ɪz saɪd. ʃi woʊv ɝθ, spɪɹəɾ ən ɛɹ ɪndə ə hilɪŋ, bʌt ʃi wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm tæləntəɾ ɪn ðɪs ɛɹiə. ʃi wɝkt ɑn, ɪn ə pænɪk. səm ə hɪz kʌlɝ ɹɪtɝn ən ðə wunz bɪɡæn tə kloʊz, bʌt ʃi kʊdn də nɪɹli ɪnʌf.

Egwene threw herself from the bed and knelt beside him, ignoring the pain of her headache. He was breathing shallowly, and had a gaping wound in his side. She wove Earth, Spirit and Air into a Healing, but she was far from talented in this area. She worked on, in a panic. Some of his color returned and the wounds began to close, but she couldn't do nearly enough.

"hɛlp!" ʃi jɛld. "ði æmɪɝlɪn nidz hɛlp!"

"Help!" she yelled. "The Amyrlin needs help!"

ɡɔɪn stɝd. "ɛɡwin," hi wɪspɝd, hɪz aɪz flʌɾɝɪŋ oʊpən.

Gawyn stirred. "Egwene," he whispered, his eyes fluttering open.

"hʌʃ, ɡɔɪn. jəɹ gɑnə bi faɪn. eɪd! tə ði æmɪɝlɪn!"

"Hush, Gawyn. You're going to be fine. Aid! To the Amyrlin!"

"ju . . . dɪdn liv ɪnʌf laɪts ɑn," hi wɪspɝd.

"You . . . didn't leave enough lights on," he whispered.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ðə mɛsədʒ aɪ sɛnt ..."

"The message I sent ..."

"wi nɛvɝ ɡɑɾ ə mɛsədʒ," ʃi sɛd. "bi stɪl. hɛlp!"

"We never got a message," she said. "Be still. Help!"

"noʊbɑdi ɪz nɪɹ. aɪ jɛld. ðə læmps ... ɪts ɡʊd . . . jə dɪdnt. . ." hi smaɪl deɪzədli. "aɪ lʌv ju."

"Nobody is near. I yelled. The lamps ... it is good . . . you didn't. . ." He smiled dazedly. "I love you."

"laɪ stɪl," ʃi sɛd. laɪt! ʃi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ.

"Lie still," she said. Light! She was crying.

ði əsæsənz wɝn jəɹ fɔɹseɪkən, ðoʊ," hi sɛd, wɝdz slɝɪŋ. "aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt."

The assassins weren't your Forsaken, though," he said, words slurring. "I was right."

ən i hæd bɪn; wʌt wɝ ðoʊz ʌnfəmɪljɝ blæk junəfɔɹmz? ʃɔn-tʃæn?

And he had been; what were those unfamiliar black uniforms? Sean-chan?

aɪ ʃəd bi dɛd, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. ɪf ɡɔɪn hædn stɑp ðiz əsæsənz, ʃiɾ əv bɪn mɝɾɝd ɪn əɹ slip ən wʊɾə vænɪʃt fɹəm tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ʃid nɛvɝ əv kɪl mɛsænə.

I should be dead, she realized. If Gawyn hadn't stopped these assassins, she'd have been murdered in her sleep and would have vanished from Tel'aran'rhiod. She'd never have killed Mesaana.

sʌɾənli, ʃi fɛlt ə ful, ɛni sɛns ə vɪktɝi kəmplitli ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ.

Suddenly, she felt a fool, any sense of victory completely evaporating.

"aɪm sɑɹi," ɡɔɪn sɛd kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz, "fɔɹ dɪsəbɪŋ ju." hi wɑz slɪpɪŋ.

"I'm sorry," Gawyn said closing his eyes, "for disobeying you." He was slipping.

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt, ɡɔɪn," ʃi sɛd, blɪŋkɪŋ əweɪ tɪɹz. "aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə bɑn jə naʊ. ɪts ði oʊnli weɪ."

"It's all right, Gawyn," she said, blinking away tears. "I'm going to bond you now. It's the only way."

hɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ ɑɹm bɪkeɪm slaɪtli mɔɹ fɝm. "noʊ. nɑɾ ənlɛs... jə wɑnt. . ."

His grip on her arm became slightly more firm. "No. Not unless... you want. . ."

"ful," ʃi sɛd, pɹipɛɹɪŋ ðə wivz. "ʌv kɔɹs aɪ wɑn jə əz maɪ wɔɹɾɝ. aɪ ɔlweɪz hæv."

"Fool," she said, preparing the weaves. "Of course I want you as my Warder. I always have."

"swɛɹ ɪt."

"Swear it."

"aɪ swɛɹ ɪt. aɪ swɛɹ ðəɾ aɪ wɑn jə əz maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, ən əz maɪ hʌzbənd" ʃi ɹɛstəɾ əɹ hæn ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən leɪd ðə wiv ɑn hɪm. "aɪ lʌv ju."

"I swear it. I swear that I want you as my Warder, and as my husband" She rested her hand on his forehead and laid the weave on him. "I love you."

hi ɡæspt. sʌɾənli, ʃi kəd fil ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz, ən ɪz peɪn, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əɹ oʊn. ænd, ɪn ɹɪtɝn, ʃi nu ðəɾ i kəd fil ðə tʃɹuθ ə hɝ wɝdz.

He gasped. Suddenly, she could feel his emotions, and his pain, as if they were her own. And, in return, she knew that he could feel the truth of her words.

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. hi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ. dɪd pipəl kɹaɪ ɪn ðɛɹ slip wən ðeɪ dʒɹim nɔɹməl dʒɹimz?

Perrin opened his eyes and took a deep breath. He was crying. Did people cry in their sleep when they dreamed normal dreams?

"laɪt bi pɹeɪzd," feɪl sɛd. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən faʊn ðət ʃi nɛl nɛks tə hɪm, əz dɪd sʌmwʌn ɛls. mɑsʊɝi?

"Light be praised," Faile said. He opened his eyes and found that she knelt next to him, as did someone else. Masuri?

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡɹæb pɛɹɪnz hɛɾ ɪn əɹ hænz, ən pɛɹɪn fɛl ði aɪsi koʊld ʌv ə hilɪŋ wɑʃ əkɹɔs hɪm. ðə wunz ɪn ɪz lɛɡ ən əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛs kloʊzd.

The Aes Sedai grabbed Perrin's head in her hands, and Perrin felt the icy cold of a Healing wash across him. The wounds in his leg and across his chest closed.

"wi tʃɹaɪd tə hil jə waɪl jə slɛpt," feɪl sɛd, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ pɛɹɪnz hɛɾ ɪn əɹ læp. "bʌɾ ɛdʒɹə stɑpt ʌs."

"We tried to Heal you while you slept," Faile said, cradling Perrin's head in her lap. "But Edarra stopped us."

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt tə bi dʌn. wʊdnt wɝk ɛniweɪ." ðət wɑz ðə waɪz wʌnz vɔɪs. pɛɹɪn kəd hɪɹ əɹ ɪn ðə tɛn sʌmwɛɹ. hi blɪŋkt ɪz aɪz. hi leɪ ɑn ɪz pælət. ɪt wɑz dɪm aʊtsaɪd.

"It is not to be done. Wouldn't work anyway." That was the Wise One's voice. Perrin could hear her in the tent somewhere. He blinked his eyes. He lay on his pallet. It was dim outside.

"ɪts bɪn lɔŋɡɝ ðən ən aʊɝ," hi sɛd. "ju ʃʊɾə lɛf baɪ naʊ.'

"It's been longer than an hour," he said. "You should have left by now.'

"hʌʃ," feɪl sɛd. "ɡeɪtweɪz ɑɹ wɝkɪŋ əɡɛn, ən ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz θɹu. oʊnli ə fju θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz ɹɪmeɪn - il ən tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, moʊsli. jə θɪŋk ðeɪd liv, jə θɪŋk aɪd liv, wɪθaʊt ju?

"Hush," Faile said. "Gateways are working again, and almost everyone is through. Only a few thousand soldiers remain - Aiel and Two Rivers men, mostly. You think they'd leave, you think I'd leave, without you?

hi sæɾ ʌp, waɪpɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊ. ɪt wɑz dæmp wɪð swɛt. hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪt vænɪʃ, əz i hæɾ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. hi feɪld, ʌv kɔɹs. ɛdʒɹə stʊd baɪ ðə fɑɹ wɔl, bɪhaɪn hɪm. ʃi wɑtʃt ɪm wɪð ə mɛʒɝɪŋ ɡeɪz.

He sat up, wiping his brow. It was damp with sweat. He tried to make it vanish, as he had in the wolf dream. He failed, of course. Edarra stood by the far wall, behind him. She watched him with a measuring gaze.

hi tɝn tə feɪl. "wi hæv tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ," hi sɛd, vɔɪs ɹæɡəd. "sleɪɝ wɪl nɑt bi wɝkɪŋ əloʊn. ðəɹ wɪl bi ə tʃɹæp, pɹɑbli ən ɑɹmi. sʌmwʌn wɪð ən ɑɹmi. ðeɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə stʃɹaɪk əɾ ɛni moʊmənt."

He turned to Faile. "We have to get away," he said, voice ragged. "Slayer will not be working alone. There will be a trap, probably an army. Someone with an army. They might try to strike at any moment."

"kæn jə stænd?" feɪl æskt.

"Can you stand?" Faile asked.

"jɛs." hi fɛlt wik, bʌɾ i mænədʒd, wɪð feɪlz hɛlp. ðə flæp ɹʌsəld ən kiæɾ ɛntɝd wɪð ə wɔɾɝskɪn. pɛɹɪn tʊk ɪt ɡɹeɪtfəli, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. ɪt sleɪkt ɪz θɝst, bʌt peɪn stɪl bɝn ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm.

"Yes." He felt weak, but he managed, with Faile's help. The flap rustled and Chiad entered with a waterskin. Perrin took it gratefully, drinking. It slaked his thirst, but pain still burned inside of him.

hupɝ. . . hi loʊɝd ðə wɔɾɝskɪn. ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, dɛθ wɑz faɪnəl. wɛɹ wəd hɑpɝz soʊl ɡoʊ?

Hoopper. . . He lowered the waterskin. In the wolf dream, death was final. Where would Hopper's soul go?

aɪ mʌs kip ɡoʊɪŋ, pɛɹɪn θɔt. si maɪ pipəl tə seɪfti. hi wɔk tə ðə tɛn flæps. hɪz lɛɡz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi mɔɹ stɛɾi.

I must keep going, Perrin thought. See my people to safety. He walked to the tent flaps. His legs were already more steady.

"aɪ si jəɹ sɑɹoʊ, maɪ hʌzbənd," feɪl sɛd, wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm, hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. "wʌt hæpənd?"

"I see your sorrow, my husband," Faile said, walking beside him, hand on his arm. "What happened?"

"aɪ lɔst ə fɹɛnd," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "fɔɹ ðə sɛkən taɪm."

"I lost a friend," Perrin said softly. "For the second time."

"hɑpɝ?" ʃi smɛl fɪɹfəl.

"Hopper?" She smelled fearful.

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"oʊ, pɛɹɪn, aɪm sɑɹi." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz tɛndɝ əz ðeɪ stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. ɪt stʊd, əloʊn, ɑn ðə mɛdoʊ ðət hæd wʌns hɛld ɪz fɔɹsɪz. ðə bɹaʊn ən jɛloʊ ɡɹæs stɪl bɔɹ ði ɪmpɹɛʃənz ə tɛns, pæðz wɔɹn daʊn tə ðə mʌɾ ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ kɹɪskɹɔs pæɾɝn. ɪt lʊk laɪk ə leɪaʊt fəɹ ə taʊn, sɛkʃənz stæmp daʊn fəɹ bɪldɪŋz, laɪnz kʌt tə bɪkʌm ɹoʊdweɪz. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɪɹli ɛmpti ʌv pipəl naʊ.

"Oh, Perrin, I'm sorry." Her voice was tender as they stepped out of the tent. It stood, alone, on the meadow that had once held his forces. The brown and yellow grass still bore the impressions of tents, paths worn down to the mud in a large crisscross pattern. It looked like a layout for a town, sections stamped down for buildings, lines cut to become roadways. But it was nearly empty of people now.

ðə ɹʌmbəlɪŋ skaɪ wɑz dɑɹk. kiæd hɛld ə læntɝn ʌp tə ɪlumɪnɪt ðə ɡɹæs ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm.

The rumbling sky was dark. Chiad held a lantern up to illuminate the grass in front of them.

sɛvɹəl ɡɹups ə soʊlʒɝz weɪɾəd. meɪɾənz ɹeɪz ðɛɹ spɪɹz haɪ wən ðeɪ sɔ hɪm, ðən bæŋd əm ɑn ðɛɹ ʃilz. ə saɪn ʌv əpɹuvəl.

Several groups of soldiers waited. Maidens raised their spears high when they saw him, then banged them on their shields. A sign of approval.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ ðəɹ əz wɛl, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɝaʊn əz wɝd spɹɛd. haʊ mʌtʃ kəd ðeɪ ɡɛs ʌv wʌt hid dʌn tənaɪt? tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn tʃɪɹd, ən pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd tə ðɛm, ðoʊ hi fɛlt ɑn ɛdʒ. ðə ɹɔŋɡnəs wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ɪn ði ɛɹ. hiɾ əsum ðət ðə dʒɹimspaɪk wɑz kɑzɪŋ ɪt, bʌɾ i hæɾ əpɛɹənli bɪn ɹɔŋ. ði ɛɹ smɛld laɪk ðə blaɪt.

The Two Rivers men were there as well, gathering around as word spread. How much could they guess of what he'd done tonight? Two Rivers men cheered, and Perrin nodded to them, though he felt on edge. The wrongness was still there, in the air. He'd assumed that the dreamspike was causing it, but he had apparently been wrong. The air smelled like the Blight.

ði æʃəmən stʊd wɛɹ ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kæmp hæd wʌns stʊd. ðeɪ tɝnd wən pɛɹɪn əpɹoʊtʃt, səluɾɪŋ, hænz tə tʃɛsts. ðeɪ lʊk tə bi ɪn ɡʊd ʃeɪp, dɪspaɪt dʒʌs hævɪŋ muvd ɔlmoʊs ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp.

The Asha'man stood where the center of the camp had once stood. They turned when Perrin approached, saluting, hands to chests. They looked to be in good shape, despite just having moved almost the entire camp.

ɡɛɾ əs aʊɾ ə hɪɹ, mɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə ðɛm. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə spɛn ənʌðɝ mɪnəɾ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs."

Get us out of here, men," Perrin said to them. "I don't want to spend another minute in this place."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ iɡɝ. hi ɡɑɾ ə lʊk ə kənsən-tʃɹeɪʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən ə smɔl ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"Yes, my Lord," Grady said, sounding eager. He got a look of concen-tration on his face, and a small gateway opened beside him.

ɪɹaʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, weɪvɪŋ tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. ðeɪ kɹɔst wɪð ə kwɪk stɛp. ðə meɪɾənz ən ɡɔl weɪɾəd wɪð pɛɹɪn, əz dɪɾ ɛlaɪəs.

Ihrough," Perrin said, waving to the Two Rivers men. They crossed with a quick step. The Maidens and Gaul waited with Perrin, as did Elyas.

laɪt, pɛɹɪn θɔt, skænɪŋ ðə fild wɛɹ ðeɪd kæmpt. aɪ fil laɪk ə maʊs biɪŋ aɪd baɪ ə hɔk.

Light, Perrin thought, scanning the field where they'd camped. I feel like a mouse being eyed by a hawk.

"aɪ doʊn səpoʊz jə kəd ɡɪv əs səm laɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə nild, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

"I don't suppose you could give us some light," Perrin said to Neald, standing beside the gateway.

ði æʃəmən kɑkt ɪz hɛd, ən ə ɡɹup ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ ɡlɑbz æp-pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn hɪm. ðeɪ zɪpt ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ðə mɛdoʊ.

The Asha'man cocked his head, and a group of glowing globes ap-peared around him. They zipped up into the air around the meadow.

ðeɪ ɪluməneɪɾəd nʌθɪŋ. dʒʌs ði əbændən kæmpsaɪt. ðə læst ə ðə tʃɹups faɪnəli faɪl θɹu.

They illuminated nothing. Just the abandoned campsite. The last of the troops finally filed through.

pɛɹɪn ən feɪl kɹɔst, ɡɔl, ɛlaɪəs ən ðə meɪɾənz ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ hɪm. faɪnəli, ðə tʃænlɝz pæs θɹu, wɔkɪŋ ɪn ə klʌstɝ.

Perrin and Faile crossed, Gaul, Elyas and the Maidens going after him. Finally, the channelers passed through, walking in a cluster.

ði ɛɹ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz kul, ən smɛld ɹifɹɛʃɪŋli klin. pɛɹɪn hædn ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ ði ivəl smɛl hæd bɪn bɑðɝɪŋ hɪm. hi ɪnheɪl dipli. ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ə ɹaɪz, səm dɪstəns fɹəm ə splæʃ ə laɪts bɪsaɪd ðə ɹɪvɝ ðət wɑz pɹɑbli waɪtbɹɪdʒ.

The air on the other side of the gateway was cool, and smelled refreshingly clean. Perrin hadn't realized how much the evil smell had been bothering him. He inhaled deeply. They were on a rise, some distance from a splash of lights beside the river that was probably Whitebridge.

hɪz tʃɹups tʃɪɹɾ əz i stɛp θɹu. ðə ɡɹeɪt kæmp wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi moʊsli sɛɾ ʌp, ɡɑɹd poʊsts ɪn pleɪs. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ hæd bɪn oʊpən ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ ɛɹiə, mɑɹkt ɔf wɪð poʊsts, nɪɹ ðə bæk.

His troops cheered as he stepped through. The great camp was already mostly set up, guard posts in place. The gateway had been opened into a large area, marked off with posts, near the back.

ðeɪɾ ɪskeɪpt. ðə kɑs hæd bɪn ɡɹeɪt, bʌt ðeɪɾ ɪskeɪpt.

They'd escaped. The cost had been great, but they'd escaped.

ɡɹeɪndəl sæt bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. ðə lɛðɝ kʊʃənz wɝ stʌft wɪð ðə daʊn ə ðə flɛdʒlɪŋ kælɪɝ, wɪtʃ dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs eɪdʒ lɪvd oʊnli ɪn ʃɑɹə. ʃi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə lʌɡʒɝi.

Graendal sat back in her chair. The leather cushions were stuffed with the down of the fledgling kallir, which during this Age lived only in Shara. She barely noticed the luxury.

ðə sɝvənt - wʌn mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd loʊn əɹ - wɑz ɑn wʌn ni bɪfɔɹ hɝ. hɪz aɪz wɝ tɛmpɛstʃuəs, ən oʊnli hæf-loʊɝd. ðɪs wʌn wɑz ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl, bʌt bɛɹli. hi nu hi wɑz junik.

The servant - one Moridin had loaned her - was on one knee before her. His eyes were tempestuous, and only half-lowered. This one was under control, but barely. He knew he was unique.

hi ɔlsoʊ sim tə noʊ ðəɾ ɪz feɪljɝ wəd fɔl əpɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ɡɹeɪndəl dɪd nɑt swɛt.

He also seemed to know that his failure would fall upon her shoulders. Graendal did not sweat.

ʃi wɑz tu kəntʃɹoʊl fəɹ ðæt. ðə ʃʌɾɝz ɑn ðə wɪndoʊ ɪn ðə waɪd, ɹɛd-taɪld ɹum bɝst oʊpən sʌɾənli, ə koʊl si wɪn bloʊɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ən pʊɾɪŋ aʊt sɛvɹəl ə ðə læmps. tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk woʊv ʌp fɹəm ðɛɹ wɪks.

She was too controlled for that. The shutters on the window in the wide, red-tiled room burst open suddenly, a cold sea wind blowing through the chamber and putting out several of the lamps. Tendrils of smoke wove up from their wicks.

ʃi wəd nɑt feɪl.

She would not fail.

"pɹipɛɹ tə spɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹæp ɛniweɪ," ʃi kəmændəd.

"Prepare to spring the trap anyway," she commanded.

"bʌt - " ðə sɝvən sɛd.

"But - " the servant said.

"du ɪt, ən də nɑt spik bæk tə wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, dɔɡ."

"Do it, and do not speak back to one of the Chosen, dog."

ðə sɝvən loʊɝɾ ɪz aɪz, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə ɹɪbɛljəs spɑɹk tə ðɛm.

The servant lowered his eyes, though there was still a rebellious spark to them.

nɛvɝ maɪnd. ʃi stɪl hæd wʌn tul lɛf tə hɝ, wʌn ʃi hæd pəzɪʃən soʊ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli. wʌn ʃi hæd pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ə moʊmən sətʃ əz ðɪs.

Never mind. She still had one tool left to her, one she had positioned so very carefully. One she had prepared for a moment such as this.

ɪt hæd tə bi dʌn kɛɹfəli. eɪbɑɹə wɑz tɑvɝən, ən soʊ stʃɹɔŋli wʌn əz tə bi fɹaɪɾənɪŋ. æɹoʊz faɪɝd fɹəm əfɑɹ wəd mɪs, ən ɪn ə taɪm ə pikfəl kɑntəmpleɪʃən, hi wəd bi əlɝɾɪd ən ɪskeɪp.

It had to be done carefully. Aybara was ta'veren, and so strongly one as to be frightening. Arrows fired from afar would miss, and in a time of peacful contemplation, he would be alerted and escape.

ʃi niɾəd ə tɛmpəst wɪð ɪm ət ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪt. ən ðɛn, ðə bleɪd wəd fɔl. ðɪs ɪz nɑt dʌn jɛt, fɔlən blæksmɪθ. nɑt baɪ ən ɪntʃ əɹ baɪ ə liɡ.

She needed a tempest with him at the center of it. And then, the blade would fall. This is not done yet, Fallen Blacksmith. Not by an inch or by a league.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 39

ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd


In the Three-fold Land

eɪvinhə fɛlt ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn. ðəɹ wɑz ə kɑmɪŋ pɝfɛkʃən tə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. wɛt-lændɝz θɔt ðə lændskeɪps junəfɔɹm kʌlɝz dʒɹæb, bʌɾ eɪvinhə faʊn əm bjuɾəfəl. sɪmpəl bɹaʊnz ən tænz. ðeɪ wɝ fəmɪljɝ ən dɪpɛndəbəl, nɑt laɪk ðə wɛtlænz, wɛɹ boʊθ ðə lændskeɪp ən ðə wɛðɝ wɝ dɪfɹən ɛvɹi taɪm jə tɝn ɝaʊnd.

Aviendha felt right again. There was a calming perfection to the Three-fold Land. Wet-landers thought the landscape's uniform colors drab, but Aviendha found them beautiful. Simple browns and tans. They were familiar and dependable, not like the wetlands, where both the landscape and the weather were different every time you turned around.

eɪvinhə ɹæn fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ naɪt, itʃ fʊt fɔlɪŋ ɑn dʌsti ɡɹaʊnd. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn mɛni mʌnθs, ʃi fɛlt əloʊn. ɪn ðə wɛtlænz, ʃi ɔlweɪz fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi wɑz biɪŋ wɑtʃt baɪ səm ɛnəmi ʃi kəd nɑt si əɹ ətæk.

Aviendha ran forward in the darkening night, each foot falling on dusty ground. For the first time in many months, she felt alone. In the wetlands, she always felt as if she was being watched by some enemy she could not see or attack.

nɑt ðət ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd wɑz seɪfɝ. fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. ðət ʃæɾoʊd pætʃ bɪniθ ðə nædʒɹə-skɹu wɑz ðə dɛn ʌv ə liθəl sneɪk. ɪf wʌn bɹʌʃt ðə spɪnli bɹæntʃəz, ðə sneɪk wəd stʃɹaɪk; ʃi hæd sin faɪv mɛn daɪ fɹəm ðoʊz baɪts. ðə dɛn wɑz mɪɹli wʌn ə ðə mɛni hæzɝdz ʃi pæs dʊɹɪŋ əɹ ɹʌn tə ɹɪɾiən. bʌt ðoʊz deɪnʒɝz wɝ ʌndɝstændəbəl. ʃi kəd si ðɛm, mɛʒɝ əm ən əvɔɪd ðɛm. ɪf ʃi daɪd fɹəm ðə sneɪks baɪɾ əɹ fɛl tə ðə lænz hit, ðə fɔlt wəd bi hɝ oʊn.

Not that the Three-fold Land was safer. Far from it. That shadowed patch beneath the nadra-scruh was the den of a lethal snake. If one brushed the spindly branches, the snake would strike; she had seen five men die from those bites. The den was merely one of the many hazards she passed during her run to Rhuidean. But those dangers were understandable. She could see them, measure them and avoid them. If she died from the snakes bite or fell to the land's heat, the fault would be her own.

ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz pɹɛfɝəbəl tə feɪs ði ɛnəmi əɹ ðə deɪnʒɝ jə kəd si ðən tə fɪɹ ðə wʌn ðət hɪd bɪhaɪn ðə feɪsəz ə laɪɪŋ wɛtləndɝz.

It was always preferable to face the enemy or the danger you could see than to fear the one that hid behind the faces of lying wetlanders.

ʃi kəntɪnjud ɹʌnɪŋ, dɪspaɪt ðə dɪmɪŋ laɪt. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə swɛɾ əɡɛn. pipəl dɪdn swɛɾ ɪnʌf ɪn ðə wɛtlænz; pɝhæps ðət wɑz wʌt meɪɾ əm soʊ ənjuʒəwəl. ɪnstɛɾ ə lɛɾɪŋ ðə sʌn wɔɹm ðɛm, ðeɪ sɔt ɹəfɹɛʃmənt. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ tə ə pɹɑpɝ swɛt tɛn tə ɡɛt klin, ðeɪ səbmɝs ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn wɔɾɝ. ðət kʊdn bi hɛlθi.

She continued running, despite the dimming light. It was good to sweat again. People didn't sweat enough in the wetlands; perhaps that was what made them so unusual. Instead of letting the sun warm them, they sought refreshment. Instead of going to a proper sweat tent to get clean, they submersed themselves in water. That couldn't be healthy.

ʃi wəd nɑt laɪ tə hɝsɛlf. eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf hæd pɑɹteɪkən ə ðoʊz lʌɡʒɝiz, ən ʃi hæd kʌm tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðoʊz bæθs ən ðə faɪn dʒɹɛsəz ɪleɪn fɔɹst əpɑn hɝ. wʌn hæd tə æknɑlɪdʒ wʌnz wiknəsəz bɪfɔɹ wʌn kəd dɪfit ðɛm. naʊ, əz ʃi ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə dʒɛnli sloʊpɪŋ ɝθ ə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, eɪvinhəz pɝspɛktɪv wɑz ɹɪstɔɹd.

She would not lie to herself. Aviendha herself had partaken of those luxuries, and she had come to enjoy those baths and the fine dresses Elayne forced upon her. One had to acknowledge one's weaknesses before one could defeat them. Now, as she ran across the gently sloping earth of the Three-fold Land, Aviendha's perspective was restored.

faɪnəli, ʃi sloʊd. əz tɛmptɪŋ əz ɪt wɑz tə tʃɹævəl ɪn ðə dɑɹk ən slip θɹu ðə deɪz hit, ɪt wɑz nɑt waɪz. ə mɪsstɛp ɪn ðə dɑɹk kəɾ ɛn jəɹ laɪf. ʃi kwɪkli kəlɛktəd səm dɛd tɑ-bɹʌʃ ən səm ɪnɑɾə bɑɹk, ðən meɪd hɝsɛlf ə kæmp ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə tʃɹəmɛndəs stoʊn.

Finally, she slowed. As tempting as it was to travel in the dark and sleep through the day's heat, it was not wise. A misstep in the dark could end your life. She quickly collected some dead ta-brush and some ina'ta bark, then made herself a camp at the side of a tremendous stone.

sun ʃi hæɾ ə faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ, ði ɔɹənʒ laɪt ɹəflɛktɪŋ ɔf ðə ɹɑk ðət taʊɝɾ oʊvɝ hɝ. ʃid sleɪn ə smɔl ʃɛlbæk ɝliɝ, ən ʃi ənɹæpt ɪt, skɪn ɪt, ðən sɛɾ ɪɾ ʌp ɑn ə spɪt. nɑt ðə moʊs dɛləkəɾ ə milz, bʌt sæɾəsfæktʃɹi.

Soon she had a fire burning, the orange light reflecting off the rock that towered over her. She'd slain a small shellback earlier, and she unwrapped it, skinned it, then set it up on a spit. Not the most delicate of meals, but satisfactory.

eɪvinhə sɛɾəld daʊn, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə faɪɝ kɹækəl, smɛlɪŋ ðə mit. jɛs, ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ʃi hædn tʃɹævəl dɝɛkli tə ɹɪɾiən, ɪnstɛd teɪkɪŋ ðə taɪm - pɹɛʃəs ðoʊ ðət taɪm wɑz - tə ɹʌn ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. ɪt hɛlpt əɹ si wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn, ən wʌt ʃi hæd bɪkʌm. eɪvinhə ðə meɪɾən wɑz ɡɔn. ʃi hæɾ ɛmbɹeɪst əɹ pæθ əz ə waɪz wʌn, ən ðət bɹɔɾ əɹ ɑnɝ bæk. ʃi hæd pɝpəs əɡɛn. əz ə waɪz wʌn, ʃi kəd hɛlp lɛɾ əɹ pipəl θɹu ðɛɹ moʊs tʃɹaɪɪŋ taɪm.

Aviendha settled down, watching the fire crackle, smelling the meat. Yes, she was glad she hadn't Traveled directly to Rhuidean, instead taking the time - precious though that time was - to run in the Three-fold Land. It helped her see what she had been, and what she had become. Aviendha the Maiden was gone. She had embraced her path as a Wise One, and that brought her honor back. She had purpose again. As a Wise One, she could help lead her people through their most trying time.

wʌns ðɪs wɑz θɹu, hɝ pipəl wəd nid tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə θɹifoʊld lænd. itʃ deɪ ɪn ðə wɛtlænz meɪɾ əm wikɝ; ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ən ɛksələn ɪɡzæmpəl. ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn sɑf ðɛɹ. haʊ kəd wʌn nɑt ɡɹoʊ sɑft ɪn ðət pleɪs? ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi əbændənd. sun.

Once this was through, her people would need to return to the Threefold Land. Each day in the wetlands made them weaker; she herself was an excellent example. She had grown soft there. How could one not grow soft in that place? It would have to be abandoned. Soon.

ʃi smaɪld, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ən kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, lɛɾɪŋ ðə deɪz fətiɡ mɛlt əweɪ.

She smiled, settling back and closing her eyes for a moment, letting the day's fatigue melt away.

hɝ fjutʃɝ sim soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ klɪɹ. ʃi wɑz tə vɪzət ɹɪɾiən, pæs θɹu ðə kɹɪstəl kɑləmz, ðən ɹɪtɝn ən kleɪm əɹ ʃɛɹ ə ɹændz hɑɹt. ʃi wəd faɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl. ʃi wəd hɛlp pɹəzɝv ðə ɹɛmnən ə ði il u sɝvaɪvd, ðən bɹɪŋ əm hoʊm wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋd.

Her future seemed so much more clear. She was to visit Rhuidean, pass through the crystal columns, then return and claim her share of Rand's heart. She would fight at the Last Battle. She would help preserve the remnant of the Aiel who survived, then bring them home where they belonged.

ə saʊn keɪm fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ kæmp.

A sound came from outside her camp.

eɪvinhə oʊpən əɹ aɪz ən dʒʌmpt ʌp, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs. ə pis ə hɝ wɑz pliz ðət ʃi naʊ ɪnstɪŋktɪvli lʊk tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɹæðɝ ðən spɪɹz ðət wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ. ʃi woʊv ə ɡloʊb ə laɪt.

Aviendha opened her eyes and jumped up, embracing the Source. A piece of her was pleased that she now instinctively looked to the One Power, rather than spears that were not there. She wove a globe of light.

ə wʊmən stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs nɪɹbaɪ, wɛɹɪŋ il ɡɑɹb. nɑt keɪɾɪnsɝ əɹ ðə ɡɑɹb ʌv ə waɪz wʌn, bʌt nɔɹməl kloʊðɪŋ: ə dɑɹk skɝɾ ən ə tæn blaʊs ən ʃɔl, ə kɝtʃəf ɑn əɹ ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ. ʃi wɑz mɪɾəl-eɪdʒɪd, ən kæɹid noʊ wɛpənz. ʃi wɑz stɪl.

A woman stood in the darkness nearby, wearing Aiel garb. Not cadin'sor or the garb of a Wise One, but normal clothing: a dark skirt and a tan blouse and shawl, a kerchief on her graying hair. She was middle-aged, and carried no weapons. She was still.

eɪvinhə ɡlæns tə ðə saɪdz. wɑz ðɪs ən æmbʊʃ? əɹ wɑz ðɪs wʊmən ə spɛktɝ? wʌn ə ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ? waɪ hædn eɪvinhə hɝɾ əɹ əpɹoʊtʃ?

Aviendha glanced to the sides. Was this an ambush? Or was this woman a specter? One of the dead walking? Why hadn't Aviendha heard her approach?

"ɡɹiɾɪŋz, waɪz wʌn," ðə wʊmən sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "maɪɾ aɪ ʃɛɹ wɔɾɝ wɪð ju? aɪm tʃɹævlɪŋ fɑɹ, ən sɔ jəɹ faɪɝ." ðə wʊmən hæd fɝoʊd skɪn, ən ʃi kəd nɑt tʃænəl -  eɪvinhə kəd sɛns ðəɾ izəli.

"Greetings, Wise One," the woman said, bowing her head. "Might I share water with you? I am traveling far, and saw your fire." The woman had furrowed skin, and she could not channel -  Aviendha could sense that easily.

"aɪ æm nɑt jɛɾ ə waɪz wʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd, wɛɹi. "aɪ kɝənli teɪk maɪ sɛkən pæθ ɪndə ɹɪɾiən."

"I am not yet a Wise One," Aviendha said, wary. "I currently take my second path into Rhuidean."

"ðɛn jəl sun faɪn mʌtʃ ɑnɝ," ðə wʊmən sɛd. "aɪ æm nɑ-koʊmi. aɪ pɹɑməs ðəɾ aɪ min jə noʊ hɑɹm, tʃaɪld."

"Then you will soon find much honor," the woman said. "I am Na-komi. I promise that I mean you no harm, child."

sʌɾənli, eɪvinhə fɛl fulɪʃ. ðə wʊmən hæɾ əpɹoʊtʃt wɪθaʊt wɛpənz dʒɹɔn. eɪvinhə hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ hɝ θɔts; ðət wɑz waɪ ʃi hædn hɝd nɑkoʊmi əpɹoʊtʃ. "ʌv kɔɹs, pliz."

Suddenly, Aviendha felt foolish. The woman had approached without weapons drawn. Aviendha had been distracted by her thoughts; that was why she hadn't heard Nakomi approach. "Of course, please."

"θæŋk ju," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə laɪɾ ən sɛɾɪŋ daʊn əɹ pæk bɪsaɪd ðə smɔl faɪɝ.

"Thank you," Nakomi said, stepping into the light and setting down her pack beside the small fire.

ʃi klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ, ðən dʒɹu səm smɔl bɹæntʃəz aʊɾ ə hɝ pæk tə bɪld ʌp ðə fleɪmz. ʃi ɹimuvd ə pɑt fəɹ ti. "maɪɾ aɪ hæv səm ə ðət wɔɾɝ?"

She clicked her tongue, then drew some small branches out of her pack to build up the flames. She removed a pot for tea. "Might I have some of that water?"

eɪvinhə ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə wɔɾɝskɪn. ʃi kəd hɑɹdli spɛɹ ə dʒɹɑp - ʃi wɑz stɪl sɛvɹəl deɪz fɹəm ɹɪɾiən - bʌɾ ɪt wəd ɡɪv əfɛns nɑt tə ɹɪspɑn tə ðə ɹɪkwɛst æftɝ ɔfɝɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ ʃeɪd.

Aviendha got out a waterskin. She could hardly spare a drop - she was still several days from Rhuidean - but it would give offense not to respond to the request after offering to share shade.

nɑkoʊmi tʊk ðə wɔɾɝskɪn ən fɪld əɹ tipɑt, wɪtʃ ʃi ðən sɛt bɪsaɪd ðə faɪɝ tə wɔɹm. "ɪɾ ɪz ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd plɛʒɝ," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, ɹaɪflɪŋ θɹu hɝ pæk, "tə kɹɔs ðə pæθ ʌv wʌn ɑn əɹ weɪ tə ɹɪɾiən. tɛl mi, wɑz jəɹ əpɹɛntəsʃɪp lɔŋ?"

Nakomi took the waterskin and filled her teapot, which she then set beside the fire to warm. "It is an unexpected pleasure," Nakomi said, rifling through her pack, "to cross the path of one on her way to Rhuidean. Tell me, was your apprenticeship long?"

"tu lɔŋ," eɪvinhə sɛd. "ðoʊ pɹaɪmɛɹəli kəz ə maɪ oʊn stʌbɝnnəs."

"Too long," Aviendha said. "Though primarily because of my own stubbornness."

"ɑ," nɑkoʊmi sɛd. "ju hæv ði ɛɹ ʌv ə wɔɹiɝ əbaʊt ju, tʃaɪld. tɛl mi, ɑɹ jə fɹəm əmʌŋ ðoʊz u wɛnt wɛst? ðə wʌnz u dʒɔɪn ðə wʌn neɪm ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn?"

"Ah," Nakomi said. "You have the air of a warrior about you, child. Tell me, are you from among those who went west? The ones who joined the one named the Car'a'carn?"

"hi ɪz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn" eɪvinhə sɛd.

"He is the Car'a'carn" Aviendha said.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ əmjuzd. ʃi ɡɑɾ aʊt səm ti livz ən ɝbz.

"I did not say that he was not," Nakomi said, sounding amused. She got out some tea leaves and herbs.

noʊ. ʃi hædn sɛd soʊ. eɪvinhə tɝn əɹ ʃɛlbæk, ən əɹ stʌmək ɹʌmbəld. ʃid nid tə ʃɛɹ əɹ mil wɪð nɑkoʊmi əz wɛl.

No. She hadn't said so. Aviendha turned her shellback, and her stomach rumbled. She'd need to share her meal with Nakomi as well.

"meɪ aɪ æsk," nɑkoʊmi sɛd. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn?"

"May I ask," Nakomi said. "What do you think of the Car'a'carn?"

aɪ lʌv hɪm, eɪvinhə θɔɾ ɪmiɾiətli. bʌt ʃi kʊdn seɪ ðæt, "aɪ θɪŋk hiz mʌtʃ ɑnɝ.

I love him, Aviendha thought immediately. But she couldn't say that, "I think he has much honor.

ən ðoʊ hiz ɪɡnɝən ə ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪz, hiz lɝnɪŋ."

And though he is ignorant of the proper ways, he is learning."

"ju hæv spɛn taɪm wɪð hɪm, ðɛn?"

"You have spent time with him, then?"

'sʌm," eɪvinhə sɛd. ðɛn, tə bi mɔɹ ɑnəst, ʃi æɾəd, "mɔɹ ðən moʊst-'

'Some," Aviendha said. Then, to be more honest, she added, "More than most-'

"hi ɪz ə wɛtləndɝ," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, θɔtfəl. "æn kɑɹəkɑɹn. tɛl mi, ɑɹ ðə wɛtlænz əz ɡlɔɹiəs əz soʊ mɛni seɪ? ɹɪvɝz soʊ waɪd jə kænɑt si ði ʌðɝ saɪd, plæns soʊ fʊl ʌv wɔɾɝ ðeɪ bɝst wən skwizd?"

"He is a wetlander," Nakomi said, thoughtful. "And Car'a'carn. Tell me, are the wetlands as glorious as so many say? Rivers so wide you cannot see the other side, plants so full of water they burst when squeezed?"

"ðə wɛtlænz ɑɹ nɑt ɡlɔɹiəs," eɪvinhə sɛd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs. ðeɪ meɪk əs wik."

"The wetlands are not glorious," Aviendha said. "They are dangerous. They make us weak."

nɑkoʊmi fɹaʊnd.

Nakomi frowned.

hu ɪz ðɪs wʊmən? ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl tə faɪn il tʃɹævlɪŋ ðə weɪst; ivən tʃɪlʒɹən lɝn tə pɹətɛk ðɛmsɛlvz. bʌt ʃəd nɑkoʊmi nɑt bi tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð fɹɛnz, fæmli? ʃi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ðə kloʊðɪŋ ʌv ə waɪz wʌn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ . . .

Who is this woman? It was not unusual to find Aiel traveling the Waste; even children learned to protect themselves. But should Nakomi not be traveling with friends, family? She did not wear the clothing of a Wise One, but there was something about her . . .

nɑkoʊmi stɝd ðə ti, ðən ɹipəzɪʃən eɪvinhəz ʃɛlbæk, pleɪsɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə koʊlz tə kʊk ɪt mɔɹ ivənli. fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ pæk, ʃi dʒɹu fɔɹθ sɛvɹəl dipɹθ ɹuts. eɪvinhəz mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz kʊk ðoʊz. nɑkoʊmi pleɪst əm ɪn ə smɔl sɝæmɪk beɪkɪŋ bɑks, ðən slɪd ðɪs ɪndə ðə koʊlz.

Nakomi stirred the tea, then repositioned Aviendha's shellback, placing it over the coals to cook it more evenly. From inside her pack, she drew forth several deepearth roots. Aviendha's mother had always cooked those. Nakomi placed them in a small ceramic baking box, then slid this into the coals.

eɪvinhə hædn ɹilaɪz ðə faɪɝ hæd ɡɹoʊn soʊ wɔɹm. wɛɹ hæɾ ɔl ðoʊz koʊlz kʌm fɹʌm?

Aviendha hadn't realized the fire had grown so warm. Where had all those coals come from?

"ju sim tʃɹʌbəld," nɑkoʊmi sɛd. "fɑɹ bi ɪt fəɹ mi tə kwɛstʃən ən əpɹɛntəs waɪz wʌn. bʌɾ aɪ də si wɝi ɪn jəɹ aɪz."

"You seem troubled," Nakomi said. "Far be it for me to question an apprentice Wise One. But I do see worry in your eyes."

eɪvinhə staɪfəld ə ɡɹɪmɑs. ʃi wʊɾə pɹəfɝd tə bi lɛft əloʊn. ən jɛt, ʃi hæɾ ɪnvaɪɾəd ðɪs wʊmən tə ʃɛɹ əɹ wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd. "aɪ æm wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ pipəl. deɪnʒɝəs taɪmz kʌm."

Aviendha stifled a grimace. She would have preferred to be left alone. And yet, she had invited this woman to share her water and shade. "I am worried about our people. Dangerous times come."

"ðə læs bæɾəl," nɑkoʊmi sɛd sɔfli. "ðə θɪŋ ðə wɛtləndɝz spik ʌv."

"The Last Battle," Nakomi said softly. "The thing the wetlanders speak of."

"jɛs. aɪ wɝi əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑn ðæt. ðə wɛtlænz, kɝʌptɪŋ əɹ pipəl. meɪkɪŋ əm sɑft."

"Yes. I worry about something beyond that. The wetlands, corrupting our people. Making them soft."

"bʌt ðə wɛtlænz ɑɹ pɑɹɾ ʌv əɹ dɛstəni, ɑɹ ðeɪ nɑt? ðə θɪŋz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz sɛd tə hæv ɹɪvild . . . ðeɪ lɪŋk əs tə ðə wɛtlænz ɪn kjʊɹiəs weɪz. əsumɪŋ wʌɾ i sɛd wɑz tʃɹu."

"But the wetlands are part of our destiny, are they not? The things the Car'a'carn is said to have revealed . . . they link us to the wetlands in curious ways. Assuming what he said was true."

"hi wəd nɑt laɪ əbaʊt ðɪs," eɪvinhə sɛd.

"He would not lie about this," Aviendha said.

ə smɔl weɪk ə bʌzɝdz kɔɾ ən flæpt pæst ɪn ðə dɑɹk naɪɾ ɛɹ. eɪvinhəz pipəlz hɪstɝi - ðə θɪŋz ɹænd ælθɹ hæd ɹɪvild - stɪl kɑz mɛni ʌv ði il ɡɹif. ɪn ɹɪɾiən, eɪvinhə wəd sun si ðɪs hɪstɝi fəɹ hɝsɛlf: ðət ði il hæd bɹoʊkən ðɛɹ vaʊz. eɪvinhəz pipəl hæd wʌns fɑloʊd, ðən əbændənd, ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif.

A small wake of buzzards cawed and flapped past in the dark night air. Aviendha's people's history - the things Rand al'Thor had revealed - still caused many of the Aiel grief. In Rhuidean, Aviendha would soon see this history for herself: that the Aiel had broken their vows. Aviendha's people had once followed, then abandoned, the Way of the Leaf.

ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ θɔts jə ɹeɪz, əpɹɛntəs," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, pɔɹɪŋ ðə ti. "aʊɝ læn hɪɹ ɪz kɔl ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. θɹi-foʊld, fəɹ ðə θɹi θɪŋz ɪt dɪd tə ʌs. ɪt pʌnɪʃt əs fəɹ sɪn. ɪt tɛstəɾ əɹ kɝədʒ. ɪt fɔɹmd ən ænvəl tə ʃeɪp ʌs."

Interesting thoughts you raise, apprentice," Nakomi said, pouring the tea. "Our land here is called the Three-fold Land. Three-fold, for the three things it did to us. It punished us for sin. It tested our courage. It formed an anvil to shape us."

"ðə θɹi-foʊld læn meɪks əs stʃɹɔŋ. soʊ, baɪ livɪŋ ɪt, wi bɪkʌm wik."

"The Three-fold Land makes us strong. So, by leaving it, we become weak."

"bʌɾ ɪf wi hæd tə kʌm hɪɹ tə bi fɔɹdʒd ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ"

"But if we had to come here to be forged into something of strength"

nɑkoʊmi sɛd, "dʌz ðət nɑt sədʒɛs ðət ðə tɛsts wi wɝ tə feɪs-ɪn ðə wɛtlænz - wɝ əz deɪnʒɝəs əz ðə θɹi-foʊld-læn ɪtsɛlf? soʊ deɪndʒɛɹoʊ ən dɪfəkəl ðət wi hæd tə kʌm hɪɹ tə pɹipɛɹ fəɹ ðɛm?" ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɑ, bʌɾ aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju wɪð ə waɪz wʌn, nɑɾ ivən ən əpɹɛntəs. aɪ hæv toʊ"

Nakomi said, "does that not suggest that the tests we were to face-in the wetlands - were as dangerous as the Three-fold-land itself? So dangero and difficult that we had to come here to prepare for them?" She shook her head. "Ah, but I should not argue with a Wise One, not even an apprentice. I have toh"

"ðɛɹ ɪz nɛvɝ toʊ fəɹ spikɪŋ waɪz wɝdz," eɪvinhə sɛd. "tɛl mi nɑkoʊmi, wɛɹ ɪz ɪt jə tʃɹævəl? wɪtʃ sɛpt ɪz jəɹ oʊn?"

"There is never toh for speaking wise words," Aviendha said. "Tell me Nakomi, where is it you travel? Which sept is your own?"

"aɪ æm fɑɹ fɹəm maɪ ɹuf," ðə wʊmən sɛd, wɪsfəl, "jɛt nɑt fɑɹ əɾ ɔl pɝhæps // ɪz fɑɹ fɹəm mi. aɪ kænɑɾ ænsɝ jəɹ kwɛstʃən, əpɹɛntəs, fəɹ ɪts nɑt maɪ pleɪs tə ɡɪv ðɪs tʃɹuθ."

"I am far from my roof," the woman said, wistful, "yet not far at all Perhaps // is far from me. I cannot answer your question, apprentice, for it is not my place to give this truth."

eɪvinhə fɹaʊnd. wʌt kaɪndə ænsɝ wɑz ðæt?

Aviendha frowned. What kind of answer was that?

"ɪt simz tə mi," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, "ðæt baɪ bɹeɪkɪŋ əɹ eɪntʃən oʊðz tə də noʊ vaɪələns, əɹ pipəl əv ɡeɪnd ɡɹeɪt toʊ"

"It seems to me," Nakomi said, "that by breaking our ancient oaths to do no violence, our people have gained great toh"

"jɛs," eɪvinhə sɛd. wʌd jə də wən jəɹ ɪntaɪɝ pipəl hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ soʊ ɑfəl?

"Yes," Aviendha said. What did you do when your entire people had done something so awful?

ðɪs ɹiləzeɪʃən wɑz wʌt hæd kɑz soʊ mɛni ʌv ði il tə bi teɪkən baɪ ðə bliknəs. ðeɪ hæd θɹoʊn daʊn ðɛɹ spɪɹz, əɹ ɹəfjuz tə ɹimuv ðə waɪɾ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn, ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðət ðɛɹ pipəl hæd sətʃ ɡɹeɪt toʊ, ɪt kəd nɛvɝ bi mɛt.

This realization was what had caused so many of the Aiel to be taken by the bleakness. They had thrown down their spears, or refused to remove the white of gai'shain, implying that their people had such great toh, it could never be met.

bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɹɔŋ. ði il toʊ kəd bi mɛt - ɪt hæd tə bi mɛt. ðət wɑz ðə pɝpəs ə sɝvɪŋ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, ðə ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪv ə ðə wʌnz tə hum ði il hæɾ ɝɪdʒənəli swɔɹn ðɛɹ oʊðz.

But they were wrong. The Aiel toh could be met - it had to be met. That was the purpose of serving the Car'a'carn, the representative of the ones to whom the Aiel had originally sworn their oaths.

"wi wɪl miɾ əɹ toʊ" eɪvinhə sɛd. "baɪ faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl."

"We will meet our toh" Aviendha said. "By fighting in the Last Battle."

ði il wəd ðɛɹfɔɹ ɹɪɡeɪn ðɛɹ ɑnɝ. wʌns jə peɪd toʊ, jə fɝɡɑɾ ɪt. tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə fɔl ðət hæd bɪn ɹipeɪd-wɑz ɛɹəɡənt. ðeɪ wəd bi fɪnɪʃt. ðeɪ kəd ɹɪtɝn ən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fil ʃeɪm fəɹ wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ðə pæst. eɪvinhə nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf.

The Aiel would therefore regain their honor. Once you paid toh, you forgot it. To remember a fault that had been repaid-was arrogant. They would be finished. They could return and no longer feel shame for what had happened in the past. Aviendha nodded to herself.

"æn soʊ," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, hændɪŋ oʊvɝ ə kʌp ə ti, "ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd wɑz əɹ pʌnɪʃmənt. wi keɪm hɪɹ tə ɡɹoʊ soʊ ðət wi kəd miɾ əɹ toʊ"

"And so," Nakomi said, handing over a cup of tea, "the Three-fold Land was our punishment. We came here to grow so that we could meet our toh"

"jɛs," eɪvinhə sɛd. ɪt fɛl klɪɹ tə hɝ.

"Yes," Aviendha said. It felt clear to her.

"soʊ, wʌns wɪv fɔt fəɹ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, wɪl əv mɛt ðət toʊ. ən ðɛɹfɔɹ wɪl əv noʊ ɹizən tə bi pʌnɪʃt fɝðɝ. ɪf ðəɾ ɪz ðə keɪs, waɪ wəd wi ɹɪtɝn tə ðɪs lænd? wəd ðət nɑt bi laɪk sikɪŋ mɔɹ pʌnɪʃmənt, wʌns toʊ ɪz mɛt?"

"So, once we have fought for the Car'a'carn, we will have met that toh. And therefore will have no reason to be punished further. If that is the case, why would we return to this land? Would that not be like seeking more punishment, once toh is met?"

eɪvinhə fɹoʊz. bʌt noʊ, ðət wɑz sɪli. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɑɹɡju wɪð nɑkoʊmi ɑn ðə pɔɪnt, bʌt ði il bɪlɔŋd ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd.

Aviendha froze. But no, that was silly. She did not want to argue with Nakomi on the point, but the Aiel belonged in the Three-fold Land.

"pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən," nɑkoʊmi sɛd, sɪpɪŋ əɹ ti. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌt wi ɑɹ, sɝvɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑz ðə pɔɪn bɪhaɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ wi dɪd. əɹ kʌs-tɑmz, əɹ ɹeɪdz ɑn itʃ ʌðɝ, əɹ hɑɹʃ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ . . . əɹ vɛɹi weɪ ʌv laɪf"

"People of the Dragon," Nakomi said, sipping her tea. "That is what we are, Serving the Dragon was the point behind everything we did. Our cus-toms, our raids on each other, our harsh training . . . our very way of life"

"jɛs," eɪvinhə sɛd.

"Yes," Aviendha said.

'æn soʊ," nɑkoʊmi sɛd sɔfli, "wʌns saɪtblɪndɝ ɪz dɪfiɾəd, wʌɾ ɪz lɛft fəɹ ʌs? pɝhæps ðɪs ɪz waɪ soʊ mɛni ɹəfjuz tə fɑloʊ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn. kəz ðeɪ wɝiɾ ət wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt. waɪ kəntɪnju ði oʊld weɪz? haʊ də wi faɪn ɑnɝ ɪn ɹeɪɾɪŋ, ɪn kɪlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ, ɪf wəɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ pɹi-nɑɹɪŋ fəɹ sətʃ ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsk? waɪ ɡɹoʊ hɑɹɾɝ? fəɹ ðə seɪk ə biɪŋ hɑɹɾ ɪtsɛlf?"

'And so," Nakomi said softly, "once Sightblinder is defeated, what is left for us? Perhaps this is why so many refused to follow the Car'a'carn. Because they worried at what it meant. Why continue the old ways? How do we find honor in raiding, in killing one another, if we are no longer pre-naring for such an important task? Why grow harder? For the sake of being hard itself?"

"aɪ . . ."

"I . . ."

"aɪm sɑɹi," nɑkoʊmi sɛd. "aɪv lɛt maɪsɛlf ɹæmbəl əɡɛn. aɪm pɹoʊn tə ɪt, aɪ fɪɹ. hɪɹ, lɛɾ əs it."

"I'm sorry," Nakomi said. "I've let myself ramble again. I am prone to it, I fear. Here, let us eat."

eɪvinhə stɑɹɾəd. ʃʊɹli ðə ɹuts wɝn dʌn jɛt. haʊɛvɝ, nɑkoʊmi pʊld əm aʊt, ən ðeɪ smɛld wʌndɝfəl. ʃi kʌt ðə ʃɛlbæk, fɪʃɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə tɪn pleɪts fɹəm əɹ pæk. ʃi sizən ðə miɾ ən ɹuts, ðən pæst ə pleɪt tə eɪvinhə.

Aviendha started. Surely the roots weren't done yet. However, Nakomi pulled them out, and they smelled wonderful. She cut the shellback, fishing a pair of tin plates from her pack. She seasoned the meat and roots, then passed a plate to Aviendha.

ʃi teɪstəd hɛzɪɾəntli. ðə fud wɑz dɪlɪʃəs. wʌndɝfəl, ivən. bɛɾɝ ðən mɛni ə fist ʃid hæɾ ɪn faɪn pæləsəz bæk ɪn ðə wɛtlænz. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə pleɪt, əmeɪzd.

She tasted hesitantly. The food was delicious. Wonderful, even. Better than many a feast she'd had in fine palaces back in the wetlands. She stared at the plate, amazed.

"ɪf jəl ɪkskjus mi," nɑkoʊmi sɛd. "aɪ nid tə si tə neɪtʃɝ." ʃi smaɪld, ɹaɪzɪŋ, ðən ʃʌfəld ɔf ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

"If you'll excuse me," Nakomi said. "I need to see to nature." She smiled, rising, then shuffled off into the darkness.

eɪvinhə eɪt kwaɪətli, dɪstɝbd baɪ wʌt hæd bɪn sɛd. wɑz nɑɾ ə wʌndɝfəl mil laɪk ðɪs, kʊkt oʊvɝ ə faɪɝ ən meɪd fɹəm hʌmbəl ɪnɡɹiɾiənts, pɹuf ðət ðə lʌɡʒɝi ʌv ðə wɛtlænz wɑznt niɾəd?

Aviendha ate quietly, disturbed by what had been said. Was not a wonderful meal like this, cooked over a fire and made from humble ingredients, proof that the luxury of the wetlands wasn't needed?

bʌt wʌt wɑz ðə pɝpəs ə ði il naʊ? ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, wʌd ðeɪ du? faɪt, jɛs. ən ðɛn? kəntɪnju tə kɪl wʌn ənʌðɝ ɑn ɹeɪdz? tə wʌɾ ɛnd?

But what was the purpose of the Aiel now? If they did not wait for the Car'a'carn, what did they do? Fight, yes. And then? Continue to kill one another on raids? To what end?

ʃi fɪnɪʃt əɹ mil, ðən θɔt fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm. tu lɔŋ. nɑkoʊmi dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn. wɝid, eɪvinhə wɛn tə sɝtʃ fəɹ hɝ, bʌt faʊnd noʊ tʃɹeɪs ə ðə wʊmən.

She finished her meal, then thought for a long time. Too long. Nakomi did not return. Worried, Aviendha went to search for her, but found no trace of the woman.

əpɑn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə faɪɝ, eɪvinhə sɔ ðət nɑkoʊmiz pæk ən pleɪt wɝ ɡɔn. ʃi weɪɾəd ʌp fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌt ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn.

Upon returning to the fire, Aviendha saw that Nakomi's pack and plate were gone. She waited up for a time, but the woman did not return.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, eɪvinhə wɛn tə slip, filɪŋ tʃɹʌbəld.

Eventually, Aviendha went to sleep, feeling troubled.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾi


CHAPTER 40

eɪ meɪkɪŋ


A Making

pɛɹɪn sæɾ əloʊn ɑn ə tʃɹi stʌmp, aɪz kloʊzd ən feɪs tə ðə dɑɹk skaɪ. ðə kæmp wɑz sɪtʃueɪɾɪd, ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊzd, ən ɹɪpɔɹts teɪkən. pɛɹɪn faɪnəli hæd taɪm tə ɹɛst.

Perrin sat alone on a tree stump, eyes closed and face to the dark sky. The camp was situated, the gateway closed, and reports taken. Perrin finally had time to rest.

ðət wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. ɹɛstɪŋ lɛɾ ɪm θɪŋk. θɪŋkɪŋ bɹɔɾ ɪm mɛmɹiz. mɛmɹiz bɹɔt peɪn.

That was dangerous. Resting let him think. Thinking brought him memories. Memories brought pain.

hi kəd smɛl ðə wɝld ɑn ðə wɪnd. leɪɝz ə sɛns, swɝlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. ðə kæmp ɝaʊn hɪm:

He could smell the world on the wind. Layers of scents, swirling together. The camp around him:

swɛɾi pipəl, spaɪsəz fəɹ kʊkɪŋ, soʊps fəɹ klinɪŋ, hɔɹs dʌŋ, ɪmoʊʃənz. ðə hɪlz ɝaʊn ðɛm:

sweaty people, spices for cooking, soaps for cleaning, horse dung, emotions. The hills around them:

dʒɹaɪd paɪn niɾəlz, mʌd fɹəm ə stʃɹim, ðə kɑɹkəs ʌv ə dɛɾ ænəməl. ðə wɝl bɪɑnd: hɪns ə dʌs fɹəm ðə dɪstən ɹoʊd, ə stæn ə lævəndɝ ðət sʌmhaʊ sɝvaɪvd ɪn ðə daɪɪŋ wɝld.

dried pine needles, mud from a stream, the carcass of a dead animal. The world beyond: hints of dust from the distant road, a stand of lavender that somehow survived in the dying world.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɑlən. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wʊlvz. boʊθ sim tɛɹəbəl saɪnz tə hɪm.

There was no pollen. There were no wolves. Both seemed terrible signs to him.

hi fɛl sɪk. fɪzɪkəli ɪl, əz ɪf ɪz stʌmək wɝ fɪld wɪð mʌɾi swɑmp wɔɾɝ, ɹɑɾɪŋ mɔs ən bɪts ə dɛd biɾəlz. hi wɑntəd tə skɹim. hi wɑntəd tə faɪn sleɪɝ ən kɪl hɪm, paʊn fɪsts ɑn ðə mænz feɪs əntɪl ðə blʌɾ ɪnɡʌlft ɪt.

He felt sick. Physically ill, as if his stomach were filled with muddy swamp water, rotting moss and bits of dead beetles. He wanted to scream. He wanted to find Slayer and kill him, pound fists on the man's face until the blood engulfed it.

fʊtstɛps əpɹoʊtʃt. feɪl. "pɛɹɪn? dʒju wɑnə tɔk?"

Footsteps approached. Faile. "Perrin? Do you want to talk?"

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. hi ʃəd bi kɹaɪɪŋ, skɹimɪŋ. bʌɾ i fɛl soʊ koʊld. koʊld ən fjʊɹiəs. ðoʊz tu dɪdnt ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ fəɹ hɪm.

He opened his eyes. He should be crying, screaming. But he felt so cold. Cold and furious. Those two didn't go together for him.

hɪz tɛn hæd bɪn sɛɾ ʌp nɪɹbaɪ; ɪts flæps flʌɾɝd ɪn ðə wɪnd. nɪɹbaɪ, ɡɔl ɹɛklən əɡɛnst ə lɛðɝlif sæpəlɪŋ. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, wʌn ə ðə fɛɹɹi-ɝz wɝk leɪt. sɑf pilz ɪn ðə naɪt. "aɪ feɪld, feɪl," pɛɹɪn wɪspɝd. "ju ɡɑt ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil" ʃi sɛd, nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. "ju seɪv ðə pipəl."

His tent had been set up nearby; its flaps fluttered in the wind. Nearby, Gaul reclined against a leatherleaf sapling. In the distance, one of the farri-ers worked late. Soft peals in the night. "I failed, Faile," Perrin whispered. "You got the ter'angreal" she said, kneeling beside him. "You saved the people."

"æn stɪl sleɪɝ biɾ ʌs," hi sɛd bɪɾɝli. "ə pæk ə faɪv ʌv əs təɡɛðɝ wɝn ɪnʌf tə faɪt hɪm."

"And still Slayer beat us," he said bitterly. "A pack of five of us together weren't enough to fight him."

pɛɹɪn hæd fɛl ðɪs weɪ wən hid faʊn ɪz fæmli dɛd, kɪl baɪ tʃɹɑləks. haʊ mɛni wɑz ðə ʃædoʊ gɑnə teɪk fɹəm ɪm baɪ ðə taɪm ðɪs wɑz dʌn? hɑpɝ ʃʊɾə bɪn seɪf ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

Perrin had felt this way when he'd found his family dead, killed by Trollocs. How many was the Shadow going to take from him by the time this was done? Hopper should have been safe in the wolf dream.

fulɪʃ kʌb, fulɪʃ kʌb.

Foolish cub, foolish cub.

hæd ðəɹ ivən ɹɪli bɪn ə tʃɹæp fəɹ pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmi? sleɪɝz dʒɹimspaɪk cʊɾə bɪn mɛn fəɹ ənʌðɝ pɝpəs ɪntaɪɝli. dʒʌst ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns.

Had there even really been a trap for Perrin's army? Slayer's dreamspike could have been meant for another purpose entirely. Just a coincidence.

ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz fəɹ tɑvɝən . . .

There are no coincidences for ta'veren . . .

hi niɾəd tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz æŋɡɝ ən ɪz peɪn. hi stʊd, tɝnɪŋ, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si haʊ mɛni laɪts stɪl ʃoʊn ɪn kæmp. ə ɡɹup ə pipəl weɪɾəd nɪɹbaɪ, fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ fɹəm ɪm ðəɾ i hædn meɪɾ aʊt ðɛɹ sɛns spəsɪfɪkli. æliændɝ ɪn ə ɡoʊldən ɡaʊn. bɪɹ- leɪn ɪn blu. boʊθ sæɾ ɑn tʃɛɹz bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl wʊɾən tʃɹævəl teɪbəl, sɛt wɪð ə læntɝn. ɛlaɪəs sæɾ ɑn ə ɹɑk bɪsaɪd ðɛm, ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz naɪf. ə dʌzən ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn - wɪl ælsin, dʒɑn aɪɛlɪn ən ɡɹeɪɔɹ fɹɛn əmʌŋ əm - hʌɾəld ɝaʊn ə faɪɹɛpɪt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɪm. ivən ɑɹɡændə ən ɡæl- lɛn wɝ ðɛɹ, spikɪŋ sɔfli.

He needed to find something to do with his anger and his pain. He stood, turning, and was surprised to see how many lights still shone in camp. A group of people waited nearby, far enough away from him that he hadn't made out their scents specifically. Alliandre in a golden gown. Bere- lain in blue. Both sat on chairs beside a small wooden travel table, set with a lantern. Elyas sat on a rock beside them, sharpening his knife. A dozen of the Two Rivers men - Wil al'Seen, Jon Ayellin and Grayor Frenn among them - huddled around a firepit, glancing at him. Even Arganda and Gal- lenne were there, speaking softly.

"ðeɪ ʃəd bi slipɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"They should be sleeping," Perrin said.

"ðeɪɹ wɝiɾ əbaʊt ju," feɪl sɛd. ʃi smɛld wɝiɾ əz wɛl. "æn ðəɹ wɝid jəl sɛn əm əweɪ, naʊ ðət ɡeɪtweɪz wɝk əɡɛn."

"They're worried about you," Faile said. She smelled worried as well. "And they're worried you will send them away, now that gateways work again."

"fulz," pɛɹɪn wɪspɝd. "fulz tə fɑloʊ mi. fulz nɑt tə haɪd."

"Fools," Perrin whispered. "Fools to follow me. Fools not to hide."

"jud ɹɪli hæv əm də ðæt?" feɪl sɛd, æŋɡɹi. "kaʊɝ sʌmpleɪs waɪl ðə læs bæɾəl hæpənz? dɪdn jə seɪ ɛvɹi mæn wəd bi niɾəd?"

"You'd really have them do that?" Faile said, angry. "Cower someplace while the Last Battle happens? Didn't you say every man would be needed?"

ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt. ɛvɹi mæn wəd bi niɾəd. hi ɹilaɪz ðət pɑɹɾ ə hɪz fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən wɑz ðəɾ i dɪdnt noʊ wʌt hiɾ ɪskeɪpt. hid ɡɑɾən əweɪ, bʌt fɹəm wʌt? fəɹ wʌt hæd hɑpɝ daɪd? nɑt noʊɪŋ ði ɛnəmiz plæn meɪd pɛɹɪn fil blaɪnd.

She was right. Every man would be needed. He realized that part of his frustration was that he didn't know what he'd escaped. He'd gotten away, but from what? For what had Hopper died? Not knowing the enemy's plan made Perrin feel blind.

hi wɔkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə stʌmp, oʊvɝ tə wɛɹ ɑɹɡændə ən ɡælɛn wɝ tɔkɪŋ. "bɹɪŋ mi əɹ mæp," hi sɛd. "ʌv ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd."

He walked away from the stump, over to where Arganda and Gallenne were talking. "Bring me our map," he said. "Of the Jehannah Road."

ɑɹɡændə kɔld oʊvɝ hɝʃənɪn ən toʊld ɪm wɛɹ tə faɪnd wʌn. hɝ-ʃænɪn ɹæn ɔf, ən pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə wɔk θɹu kæmp. təwɔɹd ðə saʊn ə mɛɾəl hɪɾɪŋ mɛɾəl, ðə fɛɹiɝ wɝkɪŋ. pɛɹɪn sim dʒɹɔn tə ɪt. ðə sɛns ə kæmp swɝld ɝaʊn hɪm, ðə skaɪ ɹʌmbəlɪŋ əbʌv hɪm.

Arganda called over Hirshanin and told him where to find one. Hir-shanin ran off, and Perrin began to walk through camp. Toward the sound of metal hitting metal, the farrier working. Perrin seemed drawn to it. The scents of camp swirled around him, the sky rumbling above him.

ði ʌðɝz tʃɹeɪld æftɝ hɪm. feɪl, bɹəleɪn ən æliændɝ, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, ɛlaɪəs, ɡɔl. ðə ɡɹup ɡɹu, ʌðɝ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪt noʊbɑdi spoʊk, ən pɛɹɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm, əntɪl i keɪm tə æɛmɪn wɝkɪŋ əɾ ən ænvəl, wʌn ə ðə kæmps hɔɹs-pʊl fɔɹdʒɪz sɛɾ ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ən bɝnɪŋ wɪð ə ɹɛd laɪt.

The others trailed after him. Faile, Berelain and Alliandre, the Two Rivers men, Elyas, Gaul. The group grew, other Two Rivers men joining it Nobody spoke, and Perrin ignored them, until he came to Aemin working at an anvil, one of the camp's horse-pulled forges set up beside him and burning with a red light.

hɝʃənɪn kɑɾ ʌp tə pɛɹɪn əz i ɝaɪvd, kæɹiɪŋ ðə mæp. pɛɹɪn ənɹoʊld ɪt, hoʊldɪŋ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪm əz æɛmɪn stɑpt ɪz wɝk, smɛlɪn kjʊɹiəs. "ɑɹɡændə, ɡælɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "tɛl mi. ɪf jə wɝ gɑnə sɛɾ ʌp ðə bɛst æmbʊʃ fəɹ ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup muvɪŋ əlɔŋ ðɪs ɹoʊd təwɔɹd luɡɹd, wɛɹ wəd jə pleɪs ɪt?"

Hirshanin caught up to Perrin as he arrived, carrying the map. Perrin unrolled it, holding it before him as Aemin stopped his work, smellin curious. "Arganda, Gallenne," Perrin said. "Tell me. If you were going to set up the best ambush for a large group moving along this road toward Lugard, where would you place it?"

"hɪɹ," ɑɹɡændə sɛd wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə loʊkeɪʃən sɛvɹəl aʊɝz fɹəm wɛɹ ðeɪd bɪn kæmpɪŋ. "si hɪɹ? ðə ɹoʊd tɝnz tə fɑloʊ ən oʊld, dʒɹaɪd-aʊt stʃɹimd. ən ɑɹmi pæsɪŋ θɹu ðəɹ wəd bi toʊɾəli ɪkspoʊz tə ən æmbʊʃ; jud bi eɪbəl tə ətæk əm fɹəm ðə haɪts hɪɹ ən hɪɹ."

"Here," Arganda said without hesitation, pointing to a location several hours from where they'd been camping. "See here? The road turns to follow an old, dried-out streambed. An army passing through there would be totally exposed to an ambush; you'd be able to attack them from the heights here and here."

ɡælɛn nɑɾəd. "jɛs. ðɪs ɪz mɑɹkt əz ən ɛksələn pleɪs fəɹ ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup tə kæmp. ət ðə beɪs ə ðət hɪl wɛɹ ðə ɹoʊd bɛnz. bʌɾ ɪf sʌmwʌnz ɑn ðə haɪts əbʌv wɪð ə maɪn tə dʒju hɑɹm, jə maɪt nɑt weɪk ʌp ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

Gallenne nodded. "Yes. This is marked as an excellent place for a large group to camp. At the base of that hill where the road bends. But if someone's on the heights above with a mind to do you harm, you might not wake up in the morning."

ɑɹɡændə nɑɾəd.

Arganda nodded.

ðə haɪts ɹoʊz flæt-tɑp tə ðə nɔɹθ ə ðə ɹoʊd; ði oʊld ɹɪvɝbɛd hæd kʌɾ ə waɪd, lɛvəl pæθweɪ ðət wɑz wɑʃt aʊt tə ðə saʊθ ən wɛst. jə kəd fɪɾ ən ɑɹmi ɑn ðoʊz haɪts.

The heights rose flat-topped to the north of the road; the old riverbed had cut a wide, level pathway that was washed out to the south and west. You could fit an army on those heights.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ ðiz?" pɛɹɪn æskt, pɔɪntɪŋ tə səm mɑɹks saʊθ ə ðə ɹoʊd.

"What are these?" Perrin asked, pointing to some marks south of the road.

"oʊld ɹuənz," ɑɹɡændə sɛd. "nʌθɪŋ ə ɹɛləvəns; ðeɪv dɪɡɹeɪɾəd tu fɑɹ tə pɹəvaɪd kʌvɝ.

"Old ruins," Arganda said. "Nothing of relevance; they've degraded too far to provide cover.

ðəɹ ɹɪli dʒʌst ə fju mɔs-kʌvɝd boʊldɝz."

They're really just a few moss-covered boulders."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz kʌmɪŋ təɡɛðɝ fəɹ hɪm. "ɑɹ ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild əslip?" hi æskt.

Perrin nodded. Something was coming together for him. "Are Grady and Neald asleep?" he asked.

"noʊ," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪ wɑntəd tə steɪ əweɪk, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ mud ɡeɪv əm ə fɹaɪt."

"No," Berelain said. "They said they wanted to stay awake, just in case. I think your mood gave them a fright."

"sɛn fəɹ ðɛm," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə noʊbɑdi ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ. "wʌn ə ðɛm nidz tə tʃɛk ɑn ðə waɪtkloʊk ɑɹmi. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ sʌmwʌn tɛlɪŋ mi ðeɪ hæd bɹoʊkən kæmp." hi dɪdnt weɪt tə si ɪf ði ɔɹɾɝ wɑz fɑloʊd. hi stɛpt ʌp tə ðə fɔɹdʒ, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn æɛmɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɡɛt səm slip, æɛmɪn. aɪ nid sʌmθɪŋ tə wɝk ɑn. hɔɹsʃuz, ɪz ɪt?"

"Send for them," Perrin said to nobody in particular. "One of them needs to check on the Whitecloak army. I remember someone telling me they had broken camp." He didn't wait to see if the order was followed. He stepped up to the forge, laying a hand on Aemin's shoulder. "Get some sleep, Aemin. I need something to work on. Horseshoes, is it?"

ðə mæn nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ pɝplɛkst. pɛɹɪn tʊk ðə mænz eɪpɹən ən ɡlʌvz, ən æɛmɪn dɪpɑɹɾəd.

The man nodded, looking perplexed. Perrin took the man's apron and gloves, and Aemin departed.

pɛɹɪn ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ɪz oʊn hæmɝ. ðə hæmɝ hid bɪn ɡɪvən ɪn tɛɹ, ə hæmɝ ðət hæd bɪn juz tə kɪl, bʌt hædn bɪn juz tə kɹieɪɾ ɪn sətʃ ə lɔŋ taɪm.

Perrin got out his own hammer. The hammer he'd been given in Tear, a hammer that had been used to kill, but hadn't been used to create in such a long time.

ðə hæmɝ kəd bi iðɝ ə wɛpən əɹ ə tul. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ə tʃɔɪs, dʒʌst əz ɛvɹiwʌn u fɑloʊɾ ɪm hæɾ ə tʃɔɪs. hɑpɝ hæɾ ə tʃɔɪs. ðə wʊlf hæd meɪd ðət tʃɔɪs, ɹɪskɪŋ mɔɹ ɪn dɪfɛns ə ðə laɪt ðən ɛni hjumən - -seɪv pɛɹɪn - wəɾ ɛvɝ ʌndɝstænd.

The hammer could be either a weapon or a tool. Perrin had a choice, just as everyone who followed him had a choice. Hopper had a choice. The wolf had made that choice, risking more in defense of the Light than any human - -save Perrin - would ever understand.

pɛɹɪn juz ðə tɑŋz tə pʊl ə smɔl lɛŋθ ə mɛɾəl fɹəm ðə koʊlz, ðən pleɪst ɪɾ ɑn ði ænvəl. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz ɑɹm ən bɪɡæn tə paʊnd.

Perrin used the tongs to pull a small length of metal from the coals, then placed it on the anvil. He raised his arm and began to pound.

ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns hid faʊn ɪz weɪ tə ə fɔɹdʒ. ɪn fækt, ðə læst i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ duɪŋ ɛni səbstæntʃəl wɝk ət wʌn wɑz bæk ɪn tiɹ, ɑn ðət pisfəl deɪ wən hid lɛft ɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm ən wɝkt ət ðət smɪθi.

It had been a long time since he'd found his way to a forge. In fact, the last he could remember doing any substantial work at one was back in Tear, on that peaceful day when he'd left his responsibilities for a short time and worked at that smithy.

jə ɑɹ laɪk ə wʊlf, hʌzbənd. feɪl hæd toʊld ɪm ðæt, ɹɪfɝɪŋ tə haʊ foʊkəst i bɪkeɪm. ðət wɑz ə θɪŋ ʌv wʊlvz; ðeɪ kəd noʊ ðə pæst ən ðə fjutʃɝ, jɛt kip ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn ðə hʌnt.

You are like a wolf, husband. Faile had told him that, referring to how focused he became. That was a thing of wolves; they could know the past and the future, yet keep their attention on the hunt.

kəɾ i də ðə seɪm? əlaʊ hɪmsɛlf tə bi kənsumd wən niɾəd, jɛt kip bæləns ɪn ʌðɝ pɑɹts ə hɪz laɪf?

Could he do the same? Allow himself to be consumed when needed, yet keep balance in other parts of his life?

ðə wɝk bɪɡæn tə əbzɔɹb hɪm. ðə ɹɪðmɪk biɾɪŋ ə hæmɝ ɑn mɛɾəl. hi flæɾənd ðə lɛŋθ ʌv aɪɝn, əkeɪʒənəli ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɪt tə ðə koʊlz ən ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ənʌðɝ wʌn, wɝkɪŋ ɑn sɛvɹəl ʃuz ət wʌns. hi hæd ðə mɛʒɝməns nɪɹbaɪ fəɹ ðə saɪzəz ʌv wʌt wɑz niɾəd. hi sloʊli bɛn ðə mɛɾəl əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ði ænvəl, ʃeɪpɪŋ ɪt. hɪz ɑɹmz bɪɡæn tə swɛt, hɪz feɪs wɔɹm baɪ ðə faɪɝ ən ðə wɝk.

The work began to absorb him. The rhythmic beating of hammer on metal. He flattened the length of iron, occasionally returning it to the coals and getting out another one, working on several shoes at once. He had the measurements nearby for the sizes of what was needed. He slowly bent the metal against the side of the anvil, shaping it. His arms began to sweat, his face warmed by the fire and the work.

nild ən ɡɹeɪɾi ɝaɪvd, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz ən mɑsʊɝi. əz pɛɹɪn wɝkt, hi noʊɾəst əm sɛndɪŋ səlɪn θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə tʃɛk ɑn ðə waɪtkloʊks. ʃi ɹɪtɝn ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ, bʌt dɪleɪɾ əɹ ɹipɔɹt, sɪns pɛɹɪn wɑz bɪzi wɪð ɪz wɝk.

Neald and Grady arrived, along with the Wise Ones and Masuri. As Perrin worked, he noticed them sending Sulin through a gateway to check on the Whitecloaks. She returned a short time later, but delayed her report, since Perrin was busy with his work.

pɛɹɪn hɛld ʌp ə hɔɹsʃu, ðən fɹaʊnd. ðɪs wɑzn dɪfəkəlt ɪnʌf wɝk. ɪt wɑz suðɪŋ, jɛs, bʌt tədeɪ hi wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ tʃælənʒɪŋ. hi fɛlt ə nid tə kɹieɪt, əz ɪf tə bæləns ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən hid sin ɪn ðə wɝld, ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən hid hɛlp kɹieɪt. ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl lɛŋθs ʌv ənwɝk stil stæk bɪsaɪd ðə fɔɹdʒ, faɪnɝ mətɪɹiəl ðən wʌt wɑz juz fəɹ ʃuz. ðeɪ wɝ pɹɑbli weɪɾɪŋ tə bi tɝn ɪndə sɔɹdz fəɹ ðə fɔɹmɝ ɹɛfjudʒiz.

Perrin held up a horseshoe, then frowned. This wasn't difficult enough work. It was soothing, yes, but today he wanted something more challenging. He felt a need to create, as if to balance the destruction he'd seen in the world, the destruction he'd helped create. There were several lengths of unworked steel stacked beside the forge, finer material than what was used for shoes. They were probably waiting to be turned into swords for the former refugees.

pɛɹɪn tʊk sɛvɹəl ə ðoʊz lɛŋθs ə stil ən sɛɾ əm ɪndə koʊlz. ðɪs fɔɹdʒ wɑzn əz naɪs əz wʌɾ i wɑz əkʌstəm tə; ðoʊ hi hæɾ ə bɛloʊz ən θɹi bæɹəlz fəɹ kwɛntʃɪŋ, ðə wɪn kul ðə mɛɾəl, ən ðə koʊlz dɪdnt ɡɛɾ əz hɑɾ əz hid laɪk. hi wɑtʃt wɪð dɪsæɾɪsfækʃən.

Perrin took several of those lengths of steel and set them into coals. This Forge wasnt as nice as what he was accustomed to; though he had a bellows and three barrels for quenching, the wind cooled the metal, and the coals didn't get as hot as he'd like. He watched with dissatisfaction.

"aɪ kən hɛlp jə wɪð ðæt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," nil sɛd fɹəm ðə saɪd.

"I can help you with that, Lord Perrin," Neald said from the side.

"hit ðə mɛɾəl ʌp, ɪf jə wɑnt."

"Heat the metal up, if you want."

pɛɹɪn aɪd hɪm, ðən nɑɾəd. hi plʌkt aʊɾ ə lɛŋθ ə stil, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp wɪð ɪz tɑŋz. "aɪ wɑn ɪɾ ə naɪs jɛloʊ-ɹɛd. nɑt soʊ hɑɾ ɪt ɡoʊz waɪt, maɪn ju."

Perrin eyed him, then nodded. He plucked out a length of steel, holding it up with his tongs. "I want it a nice yellow-red. Not so hot it goes white, mind you."

nil nɑɾəd. pɛɹɪn sɛt ðə bɑɹ ɑn ði ænvəl, tʊk aʊɾ ɪz hæmɝ ən bɪɡæn tə paʊn əɡɛn.

Neald nodded. Perrin set the bar on the anvil, took out his hammer and began to pound again.

nil stʊɾ ət ðə saɪd, kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ.

Neald stood at the side, concentrating.

pɛɹɪn lɔs hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə wɝk. fɔɪdʒ ðə stil. ɔl ɛls feɪɾəd. ðə ɹɪðmɪk paʊndɪŋ ə hæmɝ ɑn mɛɾəl, laɪk ðə biɾɪŋ ə hɪz hɑɹt, ðət ʃɪmɝɪŋ mɛɾəl, wɔɹm ən deɪnʒɝəs. ɪn ðət foʊkəs, hi faʊn klɛɹəɾi. ðə wɝld wɑz kɹækɪŋ, bɹeɪkɪŋ fɝðɝ itʃ deɪ. ɪt niɾəd hɛlp, ɹaɪt naʊ. wʌns ə θɪŋ ʃæɾɝd, jə kʊdn pʊɾ ɪt bæk təɡɛðɝ.

Perrin lost himself in the work. Foige the steel. All else faded. The rhythmic pounding of hammer on metal, like the beating of his heart, That shimmering metal, warm and dangerous. In that focus, he found clarity. The world was cracking, breaking further each day. It needed help, right now. Once a thing shattered, you couldn't put it back together.

"nild," ɡɹeɪɾiz vɔɪs sɛd. ɪt wɑz ɝdʒənt, bʌt dɪstən tə pɛɹɪn. "nild, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?"

"Neald," Grady's voice said. It was urgent, but distant to Perrin. "Neald, what are you doing?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," nild ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪt filz ɹaɪt."

"I don't know," Neald replied. "It feels right."

pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə paʊnd, hɑɹɾɝ ən hɑɹɾɝ. hi foʊldəd ðə mɛɾəl, flæɾənɪŋ pisəz əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz wʌndɝfəl ðə weɪ ði æʃəmən kɛpt ɪɾ əɾ ɪɡzækli ðə ɹaɪt tɛmpɹətʃɝ. ðət fɹid pɛɹɪn fɹəm niɾɪŋ tə ɹɪlaɪ ɑn oʊnli ə fju moʊməns ə pɝfək tɛmpɹətʃɝ bɪtwin hiɾɪŋz.

Perrin continued to pound, harder and harder. He folded the metal, flattening pieces against one another. It was wonderful the way the Asha'man kept it at exactly the right temperature. That freed Perrin from needing to rely on only a few moments of perfect temperature between heatings.

ðə mɛɾəl sim tə floʊ, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ʃeɪp baɪ hɪz wɪl əloʊn. wʌt wɑz i meɪkɪŋ? hi tʊk ði ʌðɝ tu lɛŋθs aʊɾ ə ðə fleɪmz, ðən bɪɡæn tə swɪtʃ bɪtwin ðə θɹi. ðə fɝst - ən lɑɹdʒəst  - hi foʊldəɾ əpɑn ɪtsɛlf, moʊldɪŋ ɪt, juzɪŋ ə pɹɑsɛs noʊn əz ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ wɛɹ i ɪnkɹist ɪts ɡɝθ.

The metal seemed to flow, almost as if shaped by his will alone. What was he making? He took the other two lengths out of the flames, then began to switch between the three. The first - and largest  - he folded upon itself, molding it, using a process known as shrinking where he increased its girth.

hi meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ bɔl, ðən æɾəd mɔɹ stil tə ɪɾ əntɪl ɪt wɑz nɪɹli əz lɑɹdʒ əz ə mænz hɛd.

He made it into a large ball, then added more steel to it until it was nearly as large as a man's head.

ðə sɛkən i dʒɹu, meɪkɪŋ ɪt lɔŋ ən θɪn, ðən foʊldəɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ə nɛɹoʊ ɹɑd. ðə faɪnəl, smɔləs pis i flæɾənd.

The second he drew, making it long and thin, then folded it into a narrow rod. The final, smallest piece he flattened.

hi bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt, hɪz lʌŋz wɝkɪŋ laɪk bɛloʊz. hɪz swɛt wɑz laɪk ðə kwɛntʃɪŋ wɔɾɝz.

He breathed in and out, his lungs working like bellows. His sweat was like the quenching waters.

hɪz ɑɹmz wɝ laɪk ði ænvəl. hi wɑz ðə fɔɹdʒ.

His arms were like the anvil. He was the forge.

"waɪz wʌnz, aɪ niɾ ə sɝkəl," nil sɛɾ ɝdʒənli. "naʊ. doʊn ɑɹɡju! aɪ niɾ ɪt!"

"Wise Ones, I need a circle," Neald said urgently. "Now. Don't argue! I need it!"

spɑɹks bɪɡæn tə flaɪ əz pɛɹɪn paʊndɪd. lɑɹdʒɝ ʃaʊɝz wɪð itʃ bloʊ. hi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ likɪŋ fɹəm hɪm, əz ɪf itʃ bloʊ ɪnfjuz ðə mɛɾəl wɪð ɪz oʊn stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən ɔlsoʊ hɪz oʊn filɪŋz. boʊθ wɝiz ən hoʊps. ðiz floʊd fɹəm ɪm ɪndə ðə θɹi ənɹaʊt pisəz.

Sparks began to fly as Perrin pounded. Larger showers with each blow. He felt something leaking from him, as if each blow infused the metal with his own strength, and also his own feelings. Both worries and hopes. These flowed from him into the three unwrought pieces.

ðə wɝld wɑz daɪɪŋ. hi kʊdn seɪv ɪt. ðət wɑz ɹændz dʒɑb. pɛɹɪn dʒʌst wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə hɪz sɪmpəl laɪf, dɪdn hi?

The world was dying. He couldn't save it. That was Rand's job. Perrin just wanted to go back to his simple life, didn't he?

noʊ. noʊ, hi wɑntəd feɪl, hi wɑntəd kəmplɛksəɾi. hi wɑntəd laɪf. hi kʊdn haɪd, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə pipəl u fɑloʊɾ ɪm kəd haɪd.

No. No, he wanted Faile, he wanted complexity. He wanted life. He couldn't hide, any more than the people who followed him could hide.

hi dɪdnt wɑn ðɛɹ əlidʒəns. bʌɾ i hæɾ ɪt. haʊ wəɾ i fil ɪi sʌmwʌn ɛls tʊk kəmænd, ən ðən ɡɑɾ əm kɪld?

He didn't want their allegiance. But he had it. How would he feel ii someone else took command, and then got them killed?

bloʊ æftɝ bloʊ. spɹeɪz ə spɑɹks. tu mɛni, əz ɪf i wɝ paʊndɪŋ əɡɛnst ə bʌkəɾ ə moʊltən lɪkwəd. spɑɹks splæʃt ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɪksploʊɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪz hæmɝ, flaɪɪŋ əz haɪ əz tʃɹitɑps ən spɹɛɾɪŋ tɛnz ə peɪsɪz. ðə pipəl wɑtʃɪŋ wɪθdʒɹu, ɔl seɪv ði æʃəmən ən waɪz wʌnz, hu stʊd ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊnd nild.

Blow after blow. Sprays of sparks. Too many, as if he were pounding against a bucket of molten liquid. Sparks splashed in the air, exploding from his hammer, flying as high as treetops and spreading tens of paces. The people watching withdrew, all save the Asha'man and Wise Ones, who stood gathered around Neald.

aɪ doʊnt wɑnə lid ðɛm, pɛɹɪn θɔt. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ doʊnt, hu wɪl? ɪf aɪ əbændən ðɛm, ən ðeɪ fɔl, ðən ɪɾəl bi maɪ fɔlt.

I don't want to lead them, Perrin thought. But if I don't, who will? If I abandon them, and they fall, then it will be my fault.

pɛɹɪn sɔ naʊ wʌɾ i wɑz meɪkɪŋ, wʌt hid bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɔl əlɔŋ. hi wɝk ðə lɑɹdʒəs lʌmp ɪndə ə bɹɪk ʃeɪp. ðə lɔŋ pis bim ə ɹɑd, θɪk əz θɹi fɪŋɡɝz. ðə flæt pis bɪkeɪm ə kæpɪŋ bɹækɪt, ə pis ə mɛɾəl tə ɹæp ɝaʊn ðə hɛɾ ən dʒɔɪn ɪt tə ðə ʃæft.

Perrin saw now what he was making, what he'd been trying to make all along. He worked the largest lump into a brick shape. The long piece beame a rod, thick as three fingers. The flat piece became a capping bracket, a piece of metal to wrap around the head and join it to the shaft.

ə hæmɝ. hi wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə hæmɝ. ðiz wɝ ðə pɑɹts.

A hammer. He was making a hammer. These were the parts.

hi ʌndɝstʊd naʊ.

He understood now.

hi ɡɹu tə hɪz tæsk. bloʊ æftɝ bloʊ. ðoʊz bits wɝ soʊ laʊd. itʃ bloʊ sim tə ʃeɪk ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn hɪm, ɹætlɪŋ tɛns. pɛɹɪn ɪɡzʌltɪd. hi nu wʌɾ i wɑz meɪkɪŋ. hi faɪnəli nu wʌɾ i wɑz meɪkɪŋ.

He grew to his task. Blow after blow. Those beats were so loud. Each blow seemed to shake the ground around him, rattling tents. Perrin exulted. He knew what he was making. He finally knew what he was making.

hi hædn æsk tə bɪkʌm ə liɾɝ, bʌt dɪd ðəɾ əbzɑlv ɪm ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi? pipəl niɾəd hɪm. ðə wɝl niɾəd hɪm. ænd, wɪð ən ʌndɝstændɪŋ ðət kuld ɪn ɪm laɪk moʊltən ɹɑk fɔɹmɪŋ ɪndə ə ʃeɪp, hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə lid.

He hadn't asked to become a leader, but did that absolve him of responsibility? People needed him. The world needed him. And, with an understanding that cooled in him like molten rock forming into a shape, he realized that he wanted to lead.

ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd tə bi lɔɹɾ ə ðiz pipəl, hi wɑntəd tə də ɪt hɪmsɛlf. kəz duɪŋ ɪt jɝsɛlf wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ tə si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dʌn ɹaɪt.

If someone had to be lord of these people, he wanted to do it himself. Because doing it yourself was the only way to see that it was done right.

hi juzd ɪz tʃɪzəl ən ɹɑd, ʃeɪpɪŋ ə hoʊl θɹu ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə hæmɝz hɛd, ðən ɡɹæb ðə hæft ən - ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪt fɑɹ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd -  slæmd ɪt daʊn ɪndə pleɪs. hi tʊk ðə bɹækɪɾ ən leɪd ðə hæmɝ ɑn ɪt, ðən ʃeɪpt ɪt. mɪɹ moʊməns əɡoʊ, ðɪs pɹɑsɛs hæd fɛɾ ɔf ɪz æŋɡɝ. bʌt naʊ ɪt sim tə dʒɹɔ fɔɹθ ɪz ɹɛzəluʃən, hɪz dɪtɝməneɪʃən.

He used his chisel and rod, shaping a hole through the center of the hammer's head, then grabbed the haft and - raising it far over his head -  slammed it down into place. He took the bracket and laid the hammer on it, then shaped it. Mere moments ago, this process had fed off his anger. But now it seemed to draw forth his resolution, his determination.

mɛɾəl wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əlaɪv. ɛvɹi blæksmɪθ nu ðɪs. wʌns jə hiɾəd ɪt, waɪl jə wɝkt ɪt, ɪt lɪvd. hi tʊk ɪz hæmɝ ən tʃɪzəl ən bɪɡæn tə ʃeɪp pæɾɝnz, ɹɪdʒəz, mɑɾəfəkeɪʃənz. weɪvz ə spɑɹks flu fɹəm hɪm, ðə ɹɪŋɪŋ ə hɪz hæmɝ ɛvɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ, ɛvɝ laʊɾɝ, pilɪŋ laɪk bɛlz. hi juzd ɪz tʃɪzəl ɑn ə smɔl tʃʌŋk ə stil tə fɔɹm ə ʃeɪp, ðən pleɪst ɪt daʊn ɑn tɑp ə ðə hæmɝ.

Metal was something alive. Every blacksmith knew this. Once you heated it, while you worked it, it lived. He took his hammer and chisel and began to shape patterns, ridges, modifications. Waves of sparks flew from him, the ringing of his hammer ever stronger, ever louder, pealing like bells. He used his chisel on a small chunk of steel to form a shape, then placed it down on top of the hammer.

wɪð ə ɹɔɹ, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz oʊl hæmɝ wʌn læs taɪm oʊvɝ ɪz hɛɾ ən biɾ ɪt daʊn ɑn ðə nu wʌn, ɪmpɹɪntɪŋ ði ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən əpɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hæmɝ. ə lipɪŋ wʊlf.

With a roar, he raised his old hammer one last time over his head and beat it down on the new one, imprinting the ornamentation upon the side of the hammer. A leaping wolf.

pɛɹɪn loʊɝɾ ɪz tulz. ɑn ði ænvəl - stɪl ɡloʊɪŋ wɪð ən ɪnɝ hit - -wɑz ə bjuɾəfəl hæmɝ. ə wɝk bɪɑn ɛniθɪŋ hiɾ ɛvɝ kɹieɪɾəd, əɹ θɔt ðəɾ i maɪt kɹieɪt. ɪt hæɾ ə θɪk, paʊɝfəl hɛd, laɪk ə mɔl əɹ slɛdʒ, bʌt ðə bæk wɑz fɔɹm kɹɔs-feɪs ən flæɾənd. laɪk ə blæksmɪθs tul. ɪt wɑz fɔɹ fit fɹəm bɑɾəm tə tɑp, meɪbi lɔŋɡɝ, ən ɪnɔɹməs saɪz fəɹ ə hæmɝ ə ðɪs taɪp.

Perrin lowered his tools. On the anvil - still glowing with an inner heat - -was a beautiful hammer. A work beyond anything he'd ever created, or thought that he might create. It had a thick, powerful head, like a maul or sledge, but the back was formed cross-face and flattened. Like a blacksmith's tool. It was four feet from bottom to top, maybe longer, an enormous size for a hammer of this type.

ðə hæft wɑz ɔl ə stil, sʌmθɪŋ hid nɛvɝ sin ɑn ə hæmɝ bi-fɔɹ. pɛɹɪn pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp; hi wɑz eɪbəl tə lɪft ɪt wɪð wʌn hænd, bʌt bɛɹli. ɪt wɑz hɛvi. sɑləd.

The haft was all of steel, something he'd never seen on a hammer be-fore. Perrin picked it up; he was able to lift it with one hand, but barely. It was heavy. Solid.

ði ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən wɑz ʌv ə kɹɔʃætʃ pæɾɝn wɪð ðə lipɪŋ wʊlf stæmpt ɑn wʌn saɪd. ɪt lʊk laɪk hɑpɝ. pɛɹɪn tʌtʃt ɪt wɪð ə kæl luz θʌm, ən ðə mɛɾəl kwaɪəɾəd. ɪt stɪl fɛlt wɔɹm tə ðə tʌtʃ, bʌt dɪd nɑt bɝn hɪm.

The ornamentation was of a Crosshatch pattern with the leaping wolf stamped on one side. It looked like Hopper. Perrin touched it with a cal lused thumb, and the metal quieted. It still felt warm to the touch, but did not burn him.

hi tɝn tə lʊk, ən wɑz əmeɪzd ət ðə saɪz ə ðə kɹaʊd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn stʊɾ ət ðə fɹʌnt, dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ, ɑzi ælθoʊn, wɪl ælsin ən hʌnʒɹədz mɔɹ. ɡildænɪn, kɛɹhinɪn, ændɔɹənz, meɪ-ɛnɝz. wɑtʃɪŋ, kwaɪət. ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn pɛɹɪn wɑz blækən fɹəm ðə fɔlɪŋ spɑɹks; dʒɹɑps ə sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl spɹɛɾ aʊt fɹəm ɪm laɪk ə sʌnbɝst.

He turned to look, and was amazed at the size of the crowd watching him. The Two Rivers men stood at the front, Jori Congar, Azi al'Thone, Wil al'Seen and hundreds more. Ghealdanin, Cairhienin, Andorans, May-eners. Watching, quiet. The ground around Perrin was blackened from the falling sparks; drops of silvery metal spread out from him like a sunburst.

nil fɛl tə hɪz niz, pæntɪŋ, hɪz feɪs koʊɾəd wɪð swɛt. ɡɹeɪɾi ən ðə wɪmən ə ðə sɝkəl sæt daʊn, lʊkɪŋ ɪɡzɔstəd. ɔl sɪks waɪz wʌnz hæd dʒɔɪn ɪn. wʌt hæd ðeɪ dʌn?

Neald fell to his knees, panting, his face coated with sweat. Grady and the women of the circle sat down, looking exhausted. All six Wise Ones had joined in. What had they done?

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ɪɡzɔstəd, əz ɪf ɔl ə hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ ən ɪmoʊʃən hæd bɪn fɔɹdʒd ɪndə ðə mɛɾəl. bʌɾ i kəd nɑt ɹɛst. "wɪl. wiks əɡoʊ, aɪ ɡeɪv jə ən ɔɹɾɝ. bɝn ðə bænɝz ðət bɔɹ ðə wʊlfhɛd. dɪd jə oʊbeɪ? dɪd jə bɝn ɛvɹi wʌn?"

Perrin felt exhausted, as if all of his strength and emotion had been forged into the metal. But he could not rest. "Wil. Weeks ago, I gave you an order. Burn the banners that bore the wolfhead. Did you obey? Did you burn every one?"

wɪl ælsin mɛɾ ɪz aɪz, ðən lʊk daʊn, əʃeɪmd. "lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, aɪ tʃɹaɪd. bʌt. . . laɪt, aɪ kʊdn də ɪt. aɪ kɛpt wʌn. ðə wʌn aɪd hɛlp soʊ."

Wil al'Seen met his eyes, then looked down, ashamed. "Lord Perrin, I tried. But. . . Light, I couldn't do it. I kept one. The one I'd helped sew."

"fɛtʃ ɪt, wɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hɪz oʊn vɔɪs saʊndəd laɪk stil.

"Fetch it, Wil," Perrin said. His own voice sounded like steel.

wɪl ɹæn, smɛlɪŋ fɹaɪɾənd. hi ɹɪtɝnd ʃɔɹtli, bɛɹɪŋ ə foʊldəd klɔθ, waɪt wɪð ə ɹɛd bɔɹɾɝ.

Wil ran, smelling frightened. He returned shortly, bearing a folded cloth, white with a red border.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ɪt, ðən hɛld ɪɾ ɪn ə ɹɛvɝən hænd, hæmɝ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. hi lʊkt ət ðə kɹaʊd. feɪl wɑz ðɛɹ, hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɝ. ʃi smɛl hoʊpfəl. ʃi kəd si ɪndə hɪm. ʃi nu.

Perrin took it, then held it in a reverent hand, hammer in the other. He looked at the crowd. Faile was there, hands clasped before her. She smelled hopeful. She could see into him. She knew.

"aɪ hæv tʃɹaɪd tə sɛn jə əweɪ," pɛɹɪn ənaʊns tə ðə kɹaʊd. "ju wəd nɑt ɡoʊ. aɪ hæv feɪlɪŋz. jə mʌs noʊ ðɪs. ɪf wi mɑɹtʃ tə wɔɹ, əl nɑt bi eɪbəl tə pɹətɛk jə ɔl. əl meɪk mɪsteɪks."

"I have tried to send you away," Perrin announced to the crowd. "You would not go. I have failings. You must know this. If we march to war, I will not be able to protect you all. I will make mistakes."

hi lʊkt əkɹɔs ðə kɹaʊd, miɾɪŋ ði aɪz ə ðoʊz u stʊd ðɛɹ. itʃ mæn əɹ wʊmən i lʊkt ət nɑɾəd saɪlənli. noʊ ɹɪɡɹɛts, noʊ hɛzəteɪʃənz. ðeɪ nɑɾəd.

He looked across the crowd, meeting the eyes of those who stood there. Each man or woman he looked at nodded silently. No regrets, no hesitations. They nodded.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪf jə wɪʃ ðɪs, əl æksɛp jəɹ oʊðz. əl lid ju."

Perrin took a deep breath. "If you wish this, I will accept your oaths. I will lead you."

ðeɪ tʃɪɹd hɪm. ən ɪnɔɹməs ɹɔɹ ʌv ɪksaɪtmənt. "ɡoʊldeɪniz. ɡoʊldeɪniz ðə wʊlf! tə ðə læs bæɾəl! teɪʃɝ meɪnɛðɝən!"

They cheered him. An enormous roar of excitement. "Goldeneyes. Goldeneyes the wolf! To the Last Battle! Tai'shar Manetheren!"

"wɪl!" pɛɹɪn bɛloʊd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə bænɝ. "ɹeɪz ðɪs bænɝ haɪ. doʊn teɪk ɪt daʊn əɡɛn əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl əz bɪn wʌn. aɪ mɑɹtʃ bɪniθ ðə saɪn ə ðə wʊlf. ðə ɹɛst ə ju, ɹaʊs ðə kæmp. ɡɛɾ ɛvɹi soʊlʒɝ ɹɛɾi tə faɪt. wɪv ənʌðɝ tæsk tənaɪt!"

"Wil!" Perrin bellowed, holding up the banner. "Raise this banner high. Don't take it down again until the Last Battle has been won. i march beneath the sign of the wolf. The rest of you, rouse the camp. Get every soldier ready to fight. We have another task tonight!"

ðə jʌŋ mæn tʊk ðə bænɝ ən ənfɝld ɪt, dʒɔɹi ən ɑzi dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪm ən hoʊldɪŋ ɪt soʊ ɪt dɪdn tʌtʃ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðeɪ ɹeɪzd ɪt haɪ, ɹʌn- nɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ə poʊl. ðə ɡɹup bɹoʊk ʌp, mɛn ɹʌnɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðə sʌmənz.

The young man took the banner and unfurled it, Jori and Azi joining him and holding it so it didn't touch the ground. They raised it high, run- ning to get a pole. The group broke up, men running this way and that, shouting the summons.

pɛɹɪn tʊk feɪl baɪ ðə hæn əz ʃi wɔkt ʌp tə hɪm. ʃi smɛl sæɾəsfaɪd. "ðæts ɪt, ðɛn?"

Perrin took Faile by the hand as she walked up to him. She smelled satisfied. "That's it, then?"

"noʊ mɔɹ kəmpleɪnɪŋ," hi pɹɑməst. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn laɪk kɪlɪŋ, iðɝ. əl də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn." hi lʊk daʊn ət ði ænvəl, blækən fɹəm ɪz wɝk. hɪz oʊl hæmɝ, naʊ wɔɹn ən dɛntɪd, leɪ əkɹɔs ɪt. hi fɛl sæd tə liv ɪt, bʌɾ i hæd meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən.

"No more complaining," he promised. "I don't like it. But I don't like killing, either. I'll do what must be done." He looked down at the anvil, blackened from his work. His old hammer, now worn and dented, lay across it. He felt sad to leave it, but he had made his decision.

"wʌt dɪd jə du, nild?" hi æskt əz ði æʃəmən - stɪl lʊkɪŋ peɪl__- stʌmbəld ʌp tə hɪz fit. pɛɹɪn ɹeɪz ðə nu hæmɝ, ʃoʊɪŋ ðə mæɡnɪfəsənt wɝk.

"What did you do, Neald?" he asked as the Asha'man - still looking pale__- stumbled up to his feet. Perrin raised the new hammer, showing the magnificent work.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," nil sɛd. "ɪt dʒʌst . . . wɛl, ɪt wɑz laɪk aɪ sɛd. ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt. aɪ sɔ wʌt tə du, haʊ tə pʊt ðə wivz ɪndə ðə mɛɾəl ɪtsɛlf. ɪt sim tə dʒɹɔ ðɛm ɪn, laɪk ən oʊʃən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ ʌv ə stʃɹim." hi blʌʃt, əz ɪf i θɔɾ ɪɾ ə fulɪʃ fɪɡjɝ ə spitʃ.

"I don't know, my Lord," Neald said. "It just . . . well, it was like I said. It felt right. I saw what to do, how to put the weaves into the metal itself. It seemed to draw them in, like an ocean drinking in the water of a stream." He blushed, as if he thought it a foolish figure of speech.

"ðæt saʊnz ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪt nidz ə neɪm, ðɪs hæmɝ. dʒju noʊ mʌtʃ ə ði oʊl tʌŋ?"

"That sounds right," Perrin said. "It needs a name, this hammer. Do you know much of the Old Tongue?"

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"No, my Lord."

pɛɹɪn lʊkt ət ðə wʊlf ɪmpɹɪntɪɾ ɑn ðə saɪd. "dʌz ɛniwʌn noʊ haʊ jə seɪ 'hi hu sɔɹz'?"

Perrin looked at the wolf imprinted on the side. "Does anyone know how you say 'He who soars'?"

"aɪ ... aɪ doʊnt . . ."

"I ... I don't . . ."

"mæhælaɪnɝ" bɹəleɪn sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ ʃid bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ.

"Mah'alleinir" Berelain said, stepping up from where she'd been watching.

"mæhælaɪnɝ" pɛɹɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd. "ɪt filz ɹaɪt. səlɪn? wʌɾ ə ðə waɪt-kloʊks?"

"Mah'alleinir" Perrin repeated. "It feels right. Sulin? What of the White-cloaks?"

"ðeɪ hæv meɪd kæmp, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ðə meɪɾən ɹɪplaɪd.

"They have made camp, Perrin Aybara," the Maiden replied.

"ʃoʊ mi," hi sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ɑɹɡændəz mæp.

"Show me," he said, gesturing to Arganda's map.

ʃi pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðə loʊkeɪʃən: ə pis ə læn ɑn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə hɪl, haɪts ɹʌnɪŋ tə ðə nɔɹθ ʌv ɪt, ɹoʊdweɪ kʌmɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθist, ɹæpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə saʊθ ə ðə haɪts - fɑloʊɪŋ ði eɪntʃən ɹɪvɝbɛd - ən ðən bɛndɪŋ saʊθwɝd wən ɪt hɪt ðə kæmpsaɪt baɪ ðə hɪl. fɹəm ðɛɹ, ðə ɹoʊd hɛɾəd təwɔɹd luɡɹd, bʌt ðə kæmpsaɪt wɑz pɹətɛktəd fɹəm wɪn ɑn tu saɪdz. ɪt wɑz ə pɝfəkt kæmpsaɪt, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ə pɝfək pleɪs fəɹ ən æmbʊʃ. ðə wʌn ɑɹɡændə ən ɡælɛn hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt.

She pointed out the location: a piece of land on the side of a hill, heights running to the north of it, roadway coming in from the northeast, wrapping around the south of the heights - following the ancient riverbed - and then bending southward when it hit the campsite by the hill. From there, the road headed toward Lugard, but the campsite was protected from wind on two sides. It was a perfect campsite, but also a perfect place for an ambush. The one Arganda and Gallenne had pointed out.

hi lʊkt ət ðət pæsədʒweɪ ən kæmpsaɪt, θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən ðə læs fju wiks.

He looked at that passageway and campsite, thinking of what had happened the last few weeks.

wi mɛt tʃɹævəlɝz. . . . sɛd ðət ðə mʌdz tə ðə nɔɹθ wɝ ɔlmoʊs kəmplitli ɪmpæsəbəl wɪð wæɡənz əɹ kɑɹts . . .

We met travelers. . . . said that the muds to the north were almost completely impassable with wagons or carts . . .

ə flɑk ə ʃip, ɹʌnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə pæk ɪndə ðə dʒɔz ʌv ə bist. feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə klɪf. laɪt!

A flock of sheep, running before the pack into the jaws of a beast. Faile and the others, walking toward a cliff. Light!

"ɡɹeɪɾi, nild," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪm gɑnə niɾ ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ, kən jə mænədʒ?"

"Grady, Neald," Perrin said. "I'm going to need another gateway, Can you manage?"

"aɪ θɪŋk soʊ," nil sɛd. "dʒʌst ɡɪv əs ə fju mɪnəts tə kætʃ əɹ bɹɛθ."

"I think so," Neald said. "Just give us a few minutes to catch our breath."

"vɛɹi wɛl. pəzɪʃən ɪt hɪɹ." pɛɹɪn pɔɪntəd tə ðə haɪts əbʌv ðə waɪtkloʊks' kæmp. "ɡɔl!"

"Very well. Position it here." Perrin pointed to the heights above the Whitecloaks' camp. "Gaul!"

əz juʒəwəl, ði il mæn weɪɾəd nɪɹbaɪ hi loʊpt ʌp. "aɪ wɑn jə tə ɡoʊ spik wɪð dænɪl, ɑɹɡændə, ɡælɛn. aɪ wɑn ði ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi tə kɹɔs θɹu əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ tə kip kwaɪət.

As usual, the Aiel man waited nearby He loped up. "I want you to go speak with Dannil, Arganda, Gallenne. I want the entire army to cross through as quickly as possible, but they are to keep quiet.

wi muv wɪð əz mʌtʃ stɛlθ əz ən ɑɹmi ðɪs saɪz kən mænədʒ."

We move with as much stealth as an army this size can manage."

ɡɔl nɑɾəd, ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf. ɡælɛn wɑz stɪl nɪɹbaɪ; ɡɔl stɑɹɾəd baɪ spikɪŋ wɪð hɪm.

Gaul nodded, running off. Gallenne was still nearby; Gaul started by speaking with him.

feɪl wɑtʃt pɛɹɪn, smɛlɪŋ kjʊɹiəs ən ə lɪɾəl æŋkʃəs. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə plænɪŋ, hʌzbənd?"

Faile watched Perrin, smelling curious and a little anxious. "What are you planning, husband?"

"ɪts taɪm fəɹ mi tə lid," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi lʊkt wʌn læs taɪm əɾ ɪz oʊl hæmɝ, ən leɪd fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɪts hæft. ðən i hɛftəd mæhælaɪnɝ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, fit kɹæklɪŋ ɑn dʒɹɑps ə hɑɹɾənd stil.
