"It's time for me to lead," Perrin said. He looked one last time at his old hammer, and laid fingers on its haft. Then he hefted Mah'alleinir to his shoulder and strode away, feet crackling on drops of hardened steel.

ðə tul i lɛf bɪhaɪnd wɑz ðə hæmɝ ʌv ə sɪmpəl blæksmɪθ. ðət pɝsən wəɾ ɔlweɪz bi pɑɹɾ ə pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ i kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əfɔɹd tə lɛɾ ɪm lɛd.

The tool he left behind was the hammer of a simple blacksmith. That person would always be part of Perrin, but he could no longer afford to let him lead.

fɹəm naʊ ɑn, hi wəd kæɹi ðə hæmɝ ʌv ə kɪŋ.

From now on, he would carry the hammer of a king.

feɪl ɹæn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əkɹɔs ði ænvəl əz pɛɹɪn stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, kɔlɪŋ fɝðɝ ɔɹɾɝz tə pɹipɛɹ ði ɑɹmi.

Faile ran her fingers across the anvil as Perrin strode away, calling further orders to prepare the army.

dɪɾ i ɹilaɪz haʊ hid lʊkt, stændɪŋ əmɪd ðoʊz ʃaʊɝz ə spɑɹks, itʃ bloʊ ʌv ɪz hæmɝ kɑzɪŋ ðə stil bɪfɔɹ ɪm tə pʌls ən flɛɹ tə laɪf? hɪz ɡoʊldən aɪz hæd bleɪzd əz bɹaɪtli əz ðə stil; itʃ pil ə ðə hæmɝ hæd bɪn nɪɹli dɛfənɪŋ.

Did he realize how he'd looked, standing amid those showers of sparks, each blow of his hammer causing the steel before him to pulse and flare to life? His golden eyes had blazed as brightly as the steel; each peal of the hammer had been nearly deafening.

"ɪɾ əz bɪn mɛni sɛntʃɝiz sɪns ðɪs læn əz sin ðə kɹieɪʃən ʌv ə paʊɝ-ɹɔt wɛpən,"

"It has been many centuries since this land has seen the creation of a Power-wrought weapon,"

bɹəleɪn sɛd. moʊst ʌðɝz hæd lɛf tə fɑloʊ pɝ-ɹɪnz ɔɹɾɝz, ən ðə tu wɝ əloʊn, seɪv fəɹ ɡælɛn stændɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ ən stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mæp waɪl ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "ɪɾ ɪz ə stʃɹɔŋ tælən ðə jʌŋ mæn dʒʌs dɪspleɪd. ðɪs wɪl bi ʌv jus. pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmi wɪl əv paʊɝ-ɹɔt bleɪdz tə stʃɹɛŋθən ðɛm."

Berelain said. Most others had left to follow Per-rin's orders, and the two were alone, save for Gallenne standing nearby and studying the map while rubbing his chin. "It is a strong Talent the young man just displayed. This will be of use. Perrin's army will have Power-wrought blades to strengthen them."

"ðə pɹɑsɛs sim vɛɹi dʒɹeɪnɪŋ," feɪl sɛd. "ivən ɪf nil kən ɹɪpit wʌɾ i dɪd, aɪ daʊt wɪl əv taɪm tə meɪk mɛni wɛpənz."

"The process seemed very draining," Faile said. "Even if Neald can repeat what he did, I doubt we will have time to make many weapons."

"ɛvɹi smɔl ædvæntɪdʒ hɛlps," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "ðɪs ɑɹmi jəɹ hʌzbən əz fɔɹdʒd, ɪɾəl bi sʌmθɪŋ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl. tɑvɝən ɪz ət wɝk hɪɹ. hi ɡæðɝz mɛn, ən ðeɪ lɝn wɪð əmeɪzɪŋ spiɾ ən skɪl."

"Every small advantage helps," Berelain said. "This army your husband has forged, it will be something incredible. Ta'veren is at work here. He gathers men, and they learn with amazing speed and skill."

"pɝhæps," feɪl sɛd, wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ði ænvəl sloʊli, kipɪŋ əɹ aɪz ɑn bɹəleɪn, hu stʃɹoʊld ɝaʊn ɪɾ ɑpəzət hɝ. wʌt wɑz bɹəleɪnz ɡeɪm, hɪɹ?

"Perhaps," Faile said, walking around the anvil slowly, keeping her eyes on Berelain, who strolled around it opposite her. What was Berelain's game, here?

"ðɛn wi mʌst spik wɪð hɪm," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "tɝn ɪm fɹəm ðɪs kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən."

"Then we must speak with him," Berelain said. "Turn him from this course of action."

"ðɪs kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən?" feɪl æskt, dʒɛnjəwənli kənfjuzd.

"This course of action?" Faile asked, genuinely confused.

bɹəleɪn stɑpt, hɝ aɪz əlaɪt wɪð sʌmθɪŋ. ʃi sim tɛns. ʃiz wɝid, feɪl θɔt.

Berelain stopped, her eyes alight with something. She seemed tense. She's worried, Faile thought.

wɝid dipli əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ.

Worried deeply about something.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn mʌs nɑɾ ətæk ðə waɪtkloʊks," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "pliz, jə mʌs hɛlp mi pɝsweɪd hɪm."

"Lord Perrin must not attack the Whitecloaks," Berelain said. "Please, you must help me persuade him."

"hiz nɑt gɑnə ətæk ðɛm," feɪl sɛd. ʃi wɑz ɹizənəbli sɝɾən ə ðæt.

"He's not going to attack them," Faile said. She was reasonably certain of that.

"hiz sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ə pɝfəkt æmbʊʃ," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "æʃəmən tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ, tu ɹɪvɝz boʊmən tə ʃut fɹəm ðə haɪts daʊn ɑn ðə kæmp ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. kævəlɹi tə ɹaɪd daʊn ən swip ʌp æftɝ." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, simɪŋ peɪnd. "hiz sɛɾ əm ʌp pɝfəkli. hi toʊld əm ðəɾ ɪf i ən dəmədʒɹd boʊθ sɝvaɪv ðə læs bæɾəl, hid səbmɪt tə pʌnɪʃmənt. bʌt pɛɹɪn ɪz gɑnə meɪk sɝɾən ðə waɪtkloʊks doʊn ɹitʃ ðə læs bæɾəl. hi kən kip ɪz oʊθ ðət weɪ, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ əvɔɪd tɝnɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn."

"He's setting up a perfect ambush," Berelain said. "Asha'man to use the One Power, Two Rivers bowmen to shoot from the heights down on the camp of the Children. Cavalry to ride down and sweep up after." She hesitated, seeming pained. "He's set them up perfectly. He told them that if he and Damodred both survived the Last Battle, he'd submit to punishment. But Perrin is going to make certain the Whitecloaks don't reach the Last Battle. He can keep his oath that way, but also avoid turning himself in."

feɪl ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "hid nɛvɝ də ðæt, bɹəleɪn."

Faile shook her head. "He'd never do that, Berelain."

"kæn jə bi sɝɾən?" bɹəleɪn æskt. "æbsəlutli sɝɾən?"

"Can you be certain?" Berelain asked. "Absolutely certain?"

feɪl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn tʃeɪnʒɪŋ leɪtli. moʊst ə ðə tʃeɪnʒəz wɝ ɡʊd wʌnz, sətʃ əz ɪz dɪsɪʒən tə faɪnəli æksɛp liɾɝʃɪp. ən ði æmbʊʃ bɹəleɪn spoʊk ʌv wəd meɪk ə kaɪndə pɝfəkt, ɹuθləs sɛns.

Faile hesitated. Perrin had been changing lately. Most of the changes were good ones, such as his decision to finally accept leadership. And the ambush Berelain spoke of would make a kind of perfect, ruthless sense.

bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɹɔŋ. tɛɹəbli ɹɔŋ. pɛɹɪn wʊdn də ðæt, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mʌtʃ hid tʃeɪnʒd.

But it was also wrong. Terribly wrong. Perrin wouldn't do that, no matter how much he'd changed.

ʌv ðæt, feɪl kəd bi sɝɾən.

Of that, Faile could be certain.

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "ɡɪvɪŋ ə pɹɑməs tə ɡɑləd, ðən slɔɾɝɪŋ ðə waɪtkloʊks ɪn ðɪs weɪ, ɪt wəd ɹɪp pɛɹɪn əpɑɹt. hi dʌzn θɪŋk ðət weɪ. ɪt woʊn hæpən."

"Yes," she said. "Giving a promise to Galad, then slaughtering the Whitecloaks in this way, it would rip Perrin apart. He doesn't think that way. It won't happen."

aɪ hoʊp ðət jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæd hoʊp səm sɔɹɾ ʌv əkɑmədeɪʃən kəd bi ɹitʃt wɪð ðɛɹ kəmændɝ bɪfɔɹ wi lɛft . . ."

I hope that you are right," Berelain said. "I had hoped some sort of accommodation could be reached with their commander before we left . . ."

eɪ waɪtkloʊk. laɪt! kʊdnt ʃi hæv pɪkt wʌn ə ðə noʊbəlmən ɪn kæmp tə ɡɪv əɹ ətɛnʃənz tə? wʌn u wɑzn mɛɹid? "ju ɑɹən vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət pɪkɪŋ mɛn, ɑɹ ju, bɹəleɪn?" ðə wɝdz dʒʌst slɪpt aʊt.

A Whitecloak. Light! Couldn't she have picked one of the noblemen in camp to give her attentions to? One who wasn't married? "You aren't very good at picking men, are you, Berelain?" The words just slipped out.

bɹəleɪn tɝn bæk tə feɪl, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ ɪn iðɝ ʃɑk əɹ æŋɡɝ. "ænd wʌɾ ə pɛɹɪn?"

Berelain turned back to Faile, eyes widening in either shock or anger. "And what of Perrin?"

ə tɛɹəbəl mætʃ fəɹ ju," feɪl sɛd wɪð ə snɪf. "juv ʃoʊn ðət tənaɪt, baɪ wʌt jə θɪŋk hiz keɪpəbəl ʌv."

A terrible match for you," Faile said with a sniff. "You've shown that tonight, by what you think he is capable of."

haʊ ɡʊɾ ə mætʃ i wɑz ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt. aɪ wɑz pɹɑməs hɪm."

How good a match he was is irrelevant. I was promised him."

"baɪ hum?"

"By whom?"

ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," bɹəleɪn sɛd.

The Lord Dragon," Berelain said.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"aɪ keɪm tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ," ʃi sɛd. "bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv mi - hi ivən ɡɹu æŋɡɹi wɪð maɪ ədvænsəz. aɪ ɹilaɪz ðət hi, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɪntɛndəd tə mɛɹi ə mʌtʃ haɪɝ leɪɾi, pɹɑbli ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd. ɪt meɪks sɛns - hi kænɑt teɪk ɛvɹi ɹɛlm baɪ ðə sɔɹd;

"I came to the Dragon Reborn in the Stone of Tear," she said. "But he would not have me - he even grew angry with my advances. I realized that he, the Dragon Reborn, intended to marry a much higher lady, probably Elayne Trakand. It makes sense - he cannot take every realm by the sword;

səm wɪl əv tə kʌm tə hɪm θɹu əlaɪənsəz. ændɝ ɪz vɛɹi paʊɝfəl ɪz ɹul baɪ ə wʊmən, ən wəd bi ædvənteɪdʒəs tə hoʊl θɹu mɛɹɪdʒ."

some will have to come to him through alliances. Andor is very powerful is ruled by a woman, and would be advantageous to hold through marriage."

"pɛɹɪn sɛz ɹænd dʌzn θɪŋk laɪk ðæt, bɹəleɪn," feɪl sɛd. "nɑt soʊ kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ. ɪts maɪ ɪnkləneɪʃən, tu, fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ noʊ ʌv hɪm."

"Perrin says Rand doesn't think like that, Berelain," Faile said. "Not so calculating. It's my inclination, too, from what I know of him."

"æn jə seɪ ðə seɪm θɪŋ əbaʊt pɛɹɪn. juɾ əv mi bɪliv ðəɹ ɔl soʊ sɪmpəl. wɪθaʊɾ ə wɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz."

"And you say the same thing about Perrin. You'd have me believe they're all so simple. Without a wit in their heads."

"aɪ dɪdn seɪ ðæt."

"I didn't say that."

"æn jɛt jə juz ðə seɪm oʊl pɹoʊɾɛsts. taɪɹɪŋ. wɛl, aɪ ɹilaɪzd wʌt ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɑz ɪmplaɪɪŋ, soʊ aɪ tɝn maɪ ətɛnʃənz təwɔɹd wʌn ə hɪz kloʊs ətɛndəns. pɝhæps i dɪd nɑt 'pɹɑməs'

"And yet you use the same old protests. Tiring. Well, I realized what the Lord Dragon was implying, so I turned my attentions toward one of his close attendants. Perhaps he did not 'promise'

ðɛm tə mi. ðət wɑz ə pʊɹ tʃɔɪs ʌv wɝdz. bʌɾ aɪ nu hi wəd bi plizd ɪf aɪ meɪɾ ə junjən wɪð wʌn ə hɪz kloʊs ælaɪz ən fɹɛnz. ɪndid, aɪ səspɛk ðəɾ i wɪʃt mi tə də ɪt - æftɝ ɔl, ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən dɪd pleɪs mi ən pɛɹɪn təɡɛðɝ fəɹ ðɪs mɪʃən. hi kəd nɑt bi fɹæŋk əbaʊt wʌɾ i dɪzaɪɝd, haʊɛvɝ, soʊ əz tə nɑɾ əfɛn pɛɹɪn."

them to me. That was a poor choice of words. But I knew he would be pleased if I made a union with one of his close allies and friends. Indeed, I suspect that he wished me to do it - after all, the Lord Dragon did place me and Perrin together for this mission. He could not be frank about what he desired, however, so as to not offend Perrin."

feɪl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɑn wʌn hænd, wʌt bɹəleɪn sɛd wɑz pjʊɹli fulɪʃ . . . bʌɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ, ʃi kəd si wʌt ðə wʊmən maɪɾ əv sin. ɔɹ, pɝhæps, wʌt ʃi wɪʃt tə si. tə hɝ, bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹɾ ə hʌzbən ən waɪf wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɪmɔɹəl. ðɪs wɑz pɑlətɪks. ænd, lɑdʒɪkli, ɹænd pɹɑbli ʃʊɾə wɑntəd tə taɪ neɪʃənz tə hɪm θɹu bɑnz ə mɛɹɪdʒ tə ðoʊz kloʊsəs tə hɪm.

Faile hesitated. On one hand, what Berelain said was purely foolish . . . but on the other, she could see what the woman might have seen. Or, perhaps, what she wished to see. To her, breaking apart a husband and wife was nothing immoral. This was politics. And, logically, Rand probably should have wanted to tie nations to him through bonds of marriage to those closest to him.

ðət dɪdn tʃeɪnʒ ðə fæk ðət niðɝ hi, nɔɹ pɛɹɪn, ɹəɡɑɹɾəd mæɾɝz ə ðə hɑɹɾ ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ.

That didn't change the fact that neither he, nor Perrin, regarded matters of the heart in such a way.

"aɪ hæv ɡɪvən ʌp ɑn pɛɹɪn," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "aɪ hoʊl tə maɪ pɹɑməs ðɛɹ. bʌɾ ɪt livz mi ɪn ə dɪfəkəl sɪtʃueɪʃən. aɪ hæv lɔŋ θɔt ðəɾ ə kənɛkʃən tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz minz oʊnli hoʊp ɪn meɪnteɪnɪŋ ɪndɪpɛndəns ɪn ðə kʌmɪŋ jɪɹz."

"I have given up on Perrin," Berelain said. "I hold to my promise there. But it leaves me in a difficult situation. I have long thought that a connection to the Dragon Reborn is Mayene's only hope in maintaining independence in the coming years."

"mɛɹɪdʒ ɪzən oʊnli əbaʊt kleɪmɪŋ pəlɪɾəkəl ædvæntɪdʒɪz," feɪl sɛd.

"Marriage isn't only about claiming political advantages," Faile said.

"æn jɛt ði ædvæntɪdʒɪz ɑɹ soʊ ɑbviəs ðət ðeɪ kænɑt bi ɪɡnɔɹd."

"And yet the advantages are so obvious that they cannot be ignored."

"æn ðɪs waɪtkloʊk?" feɪl æskt.

"And this Whitecloak?" Faile asked.

"hæf-bɹʌðɝ ə ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ," bɹəleɪn sɛd, blʌʃɪŋ slaɪtli. "ɪf ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən dʌz ɪntɛn tə mɛɹi ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, ðɪs wɪl ɡɪmi ə lɪŋk tə hɪm."

"Half-brother of the Queen of Andor," Berelain said, blushing slightly. "If the Lord Dragon does intend to marry Elayne Trakand, this will give me a link to him."

ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ðæt; feɪl kəd si ɪɾ ɪn ðə weɪ bɹəleɪn æktəd, ɪn ðə weɪ ʃi lʊkt wən ʃi spoʊk ʌv ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd. bʌɾ ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹæʃənəlaɪz ə pəlɪɾəkəl moʊɾəveɪʃən fəɹ ɪt, feɪl hæd noʊ ɹizən tə dɪsweɪd hɝ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt hɛlp dɪstʃɹækt əɹ fɹəm pɛɹɪn. "aɪ hæv dʌn əz jə æskt," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "æn soʊ naʊ, aɪ æsk jəɹ eɪd. ɪf ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət hiz gɑnə ətæk ðɛm, pliz dʒɔɪn mi ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsweɪd hɪm. təɡɛðɝ, pɝhæps wi kən mænədʒ ɪt." "vɛɹi wɛl," feɪl sɛd.

It was much more than that; Faile could see it in the way Berelain acted, in the way she looked when she spoke of Galad Damodred. But if she wanted to rationalize a political motivation for it, Faile had no reason to dissuade her, so long as it helped distract her from Perrin. "I have done as you asked," Berelain said. "And so now, I ask your aid. If it appears that he is going to attack them, please join me in trying to dissuade him. Together, perhaps we can manage it." "Very well," Faile said.

pɛɹɪn ɹoʊɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ʌv ən ɑɹmi ðət fɛl junəfaɪd fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. ðə flæɡ ʌv min, ðə flæɡ ʌv ɡildən, ðə bænɝz ə noʊbəl haʊsəz fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz. ivən ə fju bænɝz ðə lædz hæd meɪɾ ʌp ɹɛpɹɪzɛntɪŋ ðə pɑɹts ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. əbʌv əm ɔl flæp ðə wʊlfhɛd.

Perrin rode at the head of an army that felt unified for the first time. The flag of Mayene, the flag of Ghealdan, the banners of noble Houses from among the refugees. Even a few banners the lads had made up representing the parts of the Two Rivers. Above them all flapped the wolfhead.

lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. hi wəd nɛvɝ ɡɛt juz tə ðæt, bʌt meɪbi ðət wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ.

Lord Perrin. He would never get used to that, but maybe that was a good thing.

hi tʃɹɑɾəd stɛpɝ oʊvɝ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ əz ðə tʃɹups mɑɹtʃt pæst, səluɾɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ lɪt baɪ tɔɹtʃɪz fəɹ naʊ. hoʊpfəli ðə tʃænlɝz wəd bi eɪbəl tə laɪt ðə bæɾəlfild leɪɾɝ.

He trotted Stepper over to the side of the open gateway as the troops marched past, saluting. They were lit by torches for now. Hopefully the channelers would be able to light the battlefield later.

ə mæn keɪm ʌp bɪsaɪd stɛpɝ, ən pɛɹɪn smɛld ænəməl pɛls, loʊm ən ɹæbəts blʌd. ɛlaɪəs hæd ɡɔn hʌntɪŋ waɪl i weɪɾəd fəɹ ði ɑɹmi tə ɡæðɝ. ɪt tʊk kwaɪɾ ə kin hʌntɝ tə kætʃ ɹæbəts ət naɪt. ɛlaɪəs sɛɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɛɾɝ tʃælənʒ.

A man came up beside Stepper, and Perrin smelled animal pelts, loam and rabbits blood. Elyas had gone hunting while he waited for the army to gather. It took quite a keen hunter to catch rabbits at night. Elyas said it was a better challenge.

"ju sɛd sʌmθɪŋ tə mi wʌns, ɛlaɪəs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ju toʊl mi ðəɾ ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ ɡɹu tə laɪk ði æks, aɪ ʃəd θɹoʊ ɪɾ əweɪ."

"You said something to me once, Elyas," Perrin said. "You told me that if I ever grew to like the axe, I should throw it away."

"ðæɾ aɪ dɪd."

"That I did."

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪɾ əplaɪz tə liɾɝʃɪp, tu. ðə mɛn u doʊnt wɑn taɪɾəlz ʃəd bi ðə wʌnz u ɡɛt ðɛm, ɪt simz. soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪ kip ðəɾ ɪn maɪnd, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ maɪt də ɔl ɹaɪt."

"I think it applies to leadership, too. The men who don't want titles should be the ones who get them, it seems. So long as I keep that in mind, I think I might do all right."

ɛlaɪəs tʃʌkəld. "ðə bænɝ lʊks ɡʊd, hæŋɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ."

Elyas chuckled. "The banner looks good, hanging up there."

"ɪt fɪts mi. ɔlweɪz hæz. aɪ dʒʌs hævən ɔlweɪz fɪɾ ɪt."

"It fits me. Always has. I just haven't always fit it."

"dip θɔts, fəɹ ə blæksmɪθ."

"pɝhæps." pɛɹɪn pʊl ðə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, ðə wʌn hid faʊn ɪn meɪɾən. hi stɪl hædn mænədʒ tə ɡɛt ðə θɪŋ əpɑɹt.

"Perhaps." Perrin pulled the blacksmith's puzzle from his pocket, the one he'd found in Maiden. He still hadn't managed to get the thing apart.

"hæz ɪɾ ɛvɝ stʃɹʌk jə əz ɑd ðət blæksmɪθs sim laɪk sətʃ sɪmpəl foʊk, jɛt ðəɹ ðə wʌnz u meɪk ɔl ə ðiz blæstəd pʌzəlz ðəɾ ɑɹ soʊ hɑɹd tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt?"

"Has it ever struck you as odd that blacksmiths seem like such simple folk, yet they're the ones who make all of these blasted puzzles that are so hard to figure out?"

"nɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɪt laɪk ðæt. soʊ jəɹ wʌn ʌv ʌs, faɪnəli?" "noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, pʊɾɪŋ ðə pʌzəl əweɪ. "aɪ æm u aɪ æm. faɪnəli." hi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt hæd tʃeɪnʒd wɪðɪn hɪm. bʌt pɝhæps tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ɪt θɹu tu mʌtʃ hæd bɪn ðə pɹɑbləm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

"Never thought of it like that. So you're one of us, finally?" "No," Perrin said, putting the puzzle away. "I am who I am. Finally." He wasn't certain what had changed within him. But perhaps trying to think it through too much had been the problem in the first place.

hi nu ðət hid faʊn ɪz bæləns. hi wəd nɛvɝ bɪkʌm laɪk noʊm, ðə mæn u hæd lɔs hɪmsɛlf tə ðə wʊlf. ən ðət wɑz ɪnʌf pɛɹɪn ən ɛlaɪəs weɪɾəd fəɹ ə taɪm, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɑɹmi pæs. ðiz lɑɹdʒɝ ɡeɪtweɪz meɪɾ ɪt mʌtʃ iziɝ tə tʃɹævəl; ðeɪɾ əv ɔl ə ðə faɪt-ɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən θɹu ɪn ʌndɝ ən aʊɝ. mɛn ɹeɪz hænz tə pɝ-ɹɪn, smɛlɪŋ pɹaʊd. hɪz kənɛkʃən tə ðə wʊlvz dɪd nɑt fɹaɪɾən ðɛm; ɪn fækt, ðeɪ æktʃəli  sim lɛs wɝid naʊ ðət ðeɪ nu ðə spɪsɪfɪks ʌv ɪt. bɪfɔɹ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn spɛkjəleɪʃən. kwɛstʃənz. naʊ, ðeɪ kəd bɪɡɪn tə ɡɹoʊ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ðə tʃɹuθ. ən pɹaʊɾ ʌv ɪt.

He knew that he'd found his balance. He would never become like Noam, the man who had lost himself to the wolf. And that was enough Perrin and Elyas waited for a time, watching the army pass. These larger gateways made it much easier to Travel; they'd have all of the fight-ing men and women through in under an hour. Men raised hands to Per-rin, smelling proud. His connection to the wolves did not frighten them; in fact, they actually seemed less worried now that they knew the specifics of it. Before, there had been speculation. Questions. Now, they could begin to grow comfortable with the truth. And proud of it.

ðɛɹ lɔɹd wɑz noʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi mæn. hi wɑz sʌmθɪŋ spɛʃəl.

Their lord was no ordinary man. He was something special.

"aɪ nid tə liv, pɛɹɪn," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "tənaɪt, ɪf aɪ kæn."

"I need to leave, Perrin," Elyas said. "Tonight, if I can."

"aɪ noʊ. ðə læs hʌn əz bɪɡʌn. ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm, ɛlaɪəs. wɪl miɾ ɪn ðə nɔɹθ."

"I know. The Last Hunt has begun. Go with them, Elyas. We will meet in the north."

ði eɪdʒɪŋ wɔɹɾɝ leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɪf wi doʊn si wʌn ənʌðɝ ðɛɹ, pɝhæps wɪl miɾ ɪn ðə dʒɹim, maɪ fɹɛnd."

The aging Warder laid a hand on Perrin's shoulder. "If we don't see one another there, perhaps we'll meet in the dream, my friend."

"ðɪs ɪz ðə dʒɹim," pɛɹɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "ænd wɪl miɾ əɡɛn. əl faɪn ju, ɪf jə ɑɹ wɪð ðə wʊlvz. hʌnt wɛl, lɔŋ tuθ."

"This is the dream," Perrin said, smiling. "And we will meet again. I will find you, if you are with the wolves. Hunt well, Long Tooth."

"hʌnt wɛl, jʌŋ bʊl."

"Hunt well, Young Bull."

ɛlaɪəs vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs wɪð bɛɹli ə ɹʌsəl.

Elyas vanished into the darkness with barely a rustle.

pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt daʊn tə ðə wɔɹm hæmɝ əɾ ɪz saɪd. hi hæd θɔt ðət ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi wəd bi ənʌðɝ weɪɾ əpɑn hɪm. ən jɛt, naʊ ðəɾ i hæɾ æksɛptɪɾ ɪt, hi æktʃəli  fɛlt laɪɾɝ.

Perrin reached down to the warm hammer at his side. He had thought that responsibility would be another weight upon him. And yet, now that he had accepted it, he actually felt lighter.

pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə wɑz dʒʌst ə mæn, bʌt pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz wɑz ə sɪmbəl kɹieɪɾəd baɪ ðə pipəl u fɑloʊd hɪm. pɛɹɪn dɪdn əv ə tʃɔɪs əbaʊt ðæt; ɔl i kəd də wɑz lɛd ðə bɛst i kʊd. ɪf i dɪdnt, ðə sɪmbəl wʊdn vænɪʃ. ðə pipəl wəd dʒʌs luz feɪθ ɪn ɪt. əz pʊɹ ɛɹæm hæd.

Perrin Aybara was just a man, but Perrin Goldeneyes was a symbol created by the people who followed him. Perrin didn't have a choice about that; all he could do was lead the best he could. If he didn't, the symbol wouldn't vanish. The people would just lose faith in it. As poor Aram had.

aɪm sɑɹi, maɪ fɹɛnd, hi θɔt. jə aɪ feɪl moʊst ʌv ɔl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn lʊkɪŋ bækwɝɾ ət ðæt. hi wəd sɪmpli hæv tə kəntɪnju fɔɹwɝɾ ən də bɛɾɝ. "aɪm pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz," hi sɛd, "ðə mæn u kən spik tə wʊlvz. ən aɪ ɡɛs ðæts ə ɡʊd pɝsən tə bi."

I'm sorry, my friend, he thought. You I failed most of all. There was no point in looking backward at that. He would simply have to continue forward and do better. "I'm Perrin Goldeneyes," he said, "the man who can speak to wolves. And I guess that's a good person to be."

hi kɪk stɛpɝ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz hæd səm kɪlɪŋ tə də tənaɪt.

He kicked Stepper through the gateway. Unfortunately, Perrin Goldeneyes had some killing to do tonight.

ɡɑləɾ əwoʊk əz sun əz ɪz tɛn flæp ɹʌsəld. hi dʒɹoʊv əweɪ ðə vɛstɪdʒɪz ə hɪz dʒɹim - ə sɪli θɪŋ, ʌv ɪm daɪnɪŋ wɪð ə dɑɹk-hɛɹd bjuɾi wɪð pɝfək lɪps ən kʌnɪŋ aɪz - ən ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd.

Galad awoke as soon as his tent flap rustled. He drove away the vestiges of his dream - a silly thing, of him dining with a dark-haired beauty with perfect lips and cunning eyes - and reached for his sword.

"ɡɑləd!" ə vɔɪs hɪst. ɪt wɑz tʃɹɑm.

"Galad!" a voice hissed. It was Trom.

"wʌts ɹɔŋ?" ɡɑləɾ æskt, hæn stɪl ɑn ɪz sɔɹd.

"What's wrong?" Galad asked, hand still on his sword.

"ju wɝ ɹaɪt," tʃɹɑm sɛd.

"You were right," Trom said.

"əbaʊt wʌt?"

"About what?"

"eɪbɑɹəz ɑɹmi ɪz bæk. ɡɑləd, ðəɹ ɑn ðə haɪts dʒʌst əbʌv ʌs! wi oʊnli kɑt saɪɾ ə ðɛm baɪ æksəɾənt; əɹ mɛn wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd, əz jə toʊld ʌs."

"Aybara's army is back. Galad, they're on the heights just above us! We only caught sight of them by accident; our men were watching along the road, as you told us."

ɡɑləd kɝst, sæɾ ʌp ən ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz smɔlkloʊðz. "haʊ dɪd ðeɪ ɡɛɾ ʌp ðəɹ wɪθaʊɾ əs siɪŋ?"

Galad cursed, sat up and reached for his smallclothes. "How did they get up there without us seeing?"

"dɑɹk paʊɝz, ɡɑləd. baɪɑɝ wɑz ɹaɪt. jə sɔ haʊ fæs ðɛɹ kæmp ɛmptid."

"Dark powers, Galad. Byar was right. You saw how fast their camp emptied."

ðɛɹ skaʊts hæd ɹɪtɝn ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ. ðeɪd faʊn eɪbɑɹəz kæmpsaɪɾ ɪɹəli ɛmpti, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn pɑpjəleɪɾəd baɪ ɡoʊsts. noʊbɑdi hæd sin əm liv əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd.

Their scouts had returned an hour before. They'd found Aybara's campsite eerily empty, as if it had been populated by ghosts. Nobody had seen them leave along the road.

naʊ ðɪs. ɡɑləd dʒɹɛs kwɪkli. "ɹaʊs ðə mɛn. si ɪf jə kən də ɪt kwaɪətli. jə wɝ waɪz tə bɹɪŋ noʊ laɪt; ðət maɪɾ əv əlɝɾɪd ði ɛnəmi. hæv ðə mɛn pʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ tɛns."

Now this. Galad dressed quickly. "Rouse the men. See if you can do it quietly. You were wise to bring no light; that might have alerted the enemy. Have the men put on their armor inside their tents."

ɡɑləd hɝid tə dʒɹɛs. wʌɾ əv aɪ dʌn? ɛvɹi stɛp ə ðə weɪ, hid bɪn kɑnfəɾənt ɪn ɪz tʃɔɪsəz, jɛt ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd lɛd hɪm. eɪbɑɹə, pəzɪʃən tə ətæk, ɡɑlədz mɛn əslip. ɛvɝ sɪns mɔɹɡeɪs hæd ɹɪtɝnd, ɡɑləd hæd fɛlt ɪz wɝl kɹʌmbəlɪŋ. wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ klɪɹ tə hɪm, nɑɾ əz ɪt hæd wʌns bɪn. ðə weɪ əhɛd sim klaʊɾəd.

Galad hurried to dress. What have I done? Every step of the way, he'd been confident in his choices, yet this was where they had led him. Aybara, positioned to attack, Galad's men asleep. Ever since Morgase had returned, Galad had felt his world crumbling. What was right was no longer clear to him, not as it had once been. The way ahead seemed clouded.

wi ʃəd sɝɛndɝ, hi θɔt, əfɪksɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɪn pleɪs oʊvɝ ɪz meɪl. bʌt noʊ. tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt nɛvɝ ɡɪv ɪn tə dɑɹkfɹɛnz. haʊ kəɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðæt?

We should surrender, he thought, affixing his cloak in place over his mail. But no. Children of the Light never give in to Darkfriends. How could I think that?

ðeɪ hæd tə daɪ faɪɾɪŋ. bʌt wʌt wəd ðəɾ əkɑmplɪʃ? ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, dɛd bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl bɪɡæn?

They had to die fighting. But what would that accomplish? The end of the Children, dead before the Last Battle began?

hɪz tɛn flæps ɹʌsəld əɡɛn, ən i hæɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ aʊt, ɹɛɾi tə stʃɹaɪk.

His tent flaps rustled again, and he had his sword out, ready to strike.

The accusation set Galad on edge. "Those who walk in the Light must take no responsibility for the actions of those who follow the Shadow." A quote from Lothair Mantelar. "I have acted with honor."

'ju ʃʊɾə ətækt ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðət ɹɪdɪkjələs 'tʃɹaɪəl'"

ən ɪf ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu, ɪɾəl pɹətɛkt əs naʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd, kɑnfəɾəns stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ.

And if that is true, it will protect us now," Galad said, confidence strengthening.

noʊ," baɪɑɝ sɛd, vɔɪs ən æŋɡɹi wɪspɝ. "wi hæv lɛɾ aʊɝsɛlvz tə ðɪs. ɪf wi fɔl, ɪɾəl bi dɪzɝvd." hi lɛft wɪð ə ɹʌsəl ə ðə flæps.

No," Byar said, voice an angry whisper. "We have led ourselves to this. If we fall, it will be deserved." He left with a rustle of the flaps.

ɡɑləd stʊd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən bʌkəld ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃən ən ɹɪpɛntəns wəd weɪt.

Galad stood for a moment, then buckled on his sword. Recrimination and repentance would wait.

hi hæd tə faɪn ə weɪ tə sɝvaɪv ðɪs deɪ. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ.

He had to find a way to survive this day. if there was a way.

kaʊntɝ ðɛɹ æmbʊʃ, wɪð wʌn ə ðɛɹ oʊn, hi θɔt. hæv ðə mɛn steɪ ' ðɛɹ tɛns əntɪl ði ətæk stɑɹts, ðən sɝpɹaɪz eɪbɑɹə baɪ ɹʌʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn fɔɹs, ænd. . .

Counter their ambush, with one of their own, he thought. Have the men stay ' their tents until the attack starts, then surprise Aybara by rushing out in force, and. . .

noʊ. eɪbɑɹə wəd stɑɹt wɪð æɹoʊz, ɹeɪnɪŋ dɛθ ɑn ðə tɛns ɪt wəd bi ðə bɛst weɪ tə teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ə hɪz haɪ ɡɹaʊn ən ɪz lɔŋ. boʊmən.

No. Aybara would start with arrows, raining death on the tents It would be the best way to take advantage of his high ground and his long. bowmen.

ðə bɛs θɪŋ tə də wɑz ɡɛt ðə mɛn ɑɹmɝd, ðən əv əm bɹeɪk fɹəm ðɛɹ tɛns təɡɛðɝ ɑn ə sɪɡnəl ən ɹʌn fəɹ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ði ɑɹnɑɾi-tʃnz kəd fɔɹm ə pɪkwɔl ət ðə beɪs ə ðə haɪts.

Aybara might risk running cavalry down the steep slope leading up to the rise, but pikemen could upset that maneuver.

Faile glanced at him. He sat his mount, eyes forward. They stood atop the heights, the last of his army emerging from the gateways positioned behind. Jori Congar held a shielded lantern for Perrin. It gave the area a very faint light.

Perrin's voice was so firm, and that worried Faile. Could Berelain be right? Was he going to attack the Whitecloaks? They were an unpredictable element, for all their professions of wanting to fight in the Last Battle. They could cause more harm than help. Beyond that, there was the future sword of Galad's judgment.

The land sloped steeply down to the ancient riverbed that flanked the roadway below. The road ran from the direction of Jehannah, until it passed the base of these heights and took a turn in the direction of Lugard. Right at the bend was the hollow, sheltered against the hill, where the Whitecloaks had arranged their circles of tents.

The clouds were thin, allowing pale moonlight to coat the land in silvery white. A low fog was rolling in, staying mainly in the riverbed, deep and thick. So they attacked Damodred and his men," Faile said. "After setting uP the trap, they at least wanted to do some damage to those who might fight later on."

aɪ səspɛkt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪz bɪhaɪn ðɪs," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ɡɹeɪɾi.

I suspect one of the Forsaken is behind this," Perrin said, turning toward Grady.

"One of the Forsaken?" Alliandre said, voice rising. "We can't fight one of the Forsaken?

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ət hɝ. "wʌt dɪd jə θɪŋk jə wɝ saɪnɪŋ ʌp tə du, æliændɝ, wən jə dʒɔɪn mi? jə faɪt fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn tɑɹ-moʊn ɡdən ɪtsɛlf. wɪl əv tə feɪs ðə fɔɹseɪkən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ."

Perrin glanced at her. "What did you think you were signing up to do, Alliandre, when you joined me? You fight for the Dragon Reborn in Tar-mon Gai'don itself. We'll have to face the Forsaken sooner or later."

ʃi peɪld, bʌt tə hɝ kɹɛɾət, ʃi nɑɾəd.

She paled, but to her credit, she nodded.

"ɡɹeɪɾi.'" pɛɹɪn kɔl tə ði æʃəmən, hu wɑz faɪɹɪŋ blæsts daʊn ət ðə tʃɹɑləks. "ju stɪl sɛns tʃænəlɪŋ?"

"Grady.'" Perrin called to the Asha'man, who was firing blasts down at the Trollocs. "You still sense channeling?"

"oʊnli ɔf ən ɑn, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi kɔl bæk. "huɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, ðəɹ nɑt tɛɹəbli stʃɹɔŋ. ən ðəɹ nɑt dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə bæɾəl. aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ mʌs bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks, dʒʌmpɪŋ ɪn wɪð fɪsts ə ðɛm, ðən dʒʌmpɪŋ əweɪ ɪmiɾiətli tə fɛtʃ mɔɹ."

"Only off and on, my Lord," Grady called back. "Whoever it is, they're not terribly strong. And they're not joining the battle. I think they must be doing something to bring the Trollocs, jumping in with fists of them, then jumping away immediately to fetch more."

"wɑtʃ fəɹ hɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "si ɪf jə kən teɪk ɪm daʊn."

"Watch for him," Perrin said. "See if you can take him down."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, səluɾɪŋ.

"Yes, my Lord," Grady said, saluting.

soʊ ɪt wɑznt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks dɝɛkli. ðət dɪdn min ðɪs wɑzn ðə wɝk ʌv wʌn ə ðɛm, dʒʌs ðət ðeɪ hædn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kəmɪt ðɛmsɛlvz dɝɛkli. "bæk wɪð jə θɹi," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə feɪl, bɹəleɪn ən æliændɝ, hɛftɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd bɪɡʌn tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹaɪz, mɛni dʒɹɑpɪŋ tə æɹoʊz, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ɪnʌf ðət səm wəd ɹitʃ ðə tɑp sun. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə faɪt.

So it wasn't one of the Forsaken bringing the Trollocs directly. That didn't mean this wasn't the work of one of them, just that they hadn't decided to commit themselves directly. "Back with you three," Perrin said to Faile, Berelain and Alliandre, hefting his hammer. The Trollocs had begun charging up the rise, many dropping to arrows, but there were enough that some would reach the top soon. It was time to fight.

"ju doʊnt noʊ haʊ mɛni ʌv əm ðəɹ ɑɹ, maɪ hʌzbənd," feɪl sɛd sɔfli. "ðeɪ kip kʌmɪŋ.

"You don't know how many of them there are, my husband," Faile said softly. "They keep coming.

wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ oʊvɝwɛlm ʌs?"

What if they overwhelm us?"

"wil ɹitʃɹit θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪf θɪŋz tɝn pʊɹ fəɹ ʌs. bʌɾ aɪm nɑt lɛɾɪŋ əm əv ðə waɪtkloʊks wɪθaʊɾ ə faɪt - aɪ woʊn liv ɛni mæn tə ðə tʃɹɑləks, nɑɾ ivən ðɛɹ lɑt. ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wən wi wɝ ətækt. wɛl, aɪ woʊn də ðə seɪm. ən ðæts ðæt."

"We'll retreat through a gateway if things turn poor for us. But I'm not letting them have the Whitecloaks without a fight - I won't leave any man to the Trollocs, not even their lot. They ignored the Two Rivers when we were attacked. Well, I won't do the same. And that's that."

feɪl, sʌɾənli, lin oʊvɝ tə kɪs hɪm. "θæŋk ju."

Faile, suddenly, leaned over to kiss him. "Thank you."

"fɔɹ wʌt?"

"fɔɹ biɪŋ ðə mæn ðət jə ɑɹ," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əɹ maʊn ən liɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ tu əweɪ.

"For being the man that you are," she said, turning her mount and leading the other two away.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi hæd bɪn wɝiɪŋ ðət hid nid tə hæv ɡɹeɪɾi ɹæp əɹ ʌp ɪn ɛɹ ən toʊ hɝ əweɪ. hi tɝn bæk tə ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝn meɪkɪŋ ɪɾ izi fəɹ əm tə ɡɛɾ ʌp ði ɪnklaɪn. ðə mɛn wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv æɹoʊz, ðoʊ.

Perrin shook his head. He had been worrying that he'd need to have Grady wrap her up in Air and tow her away. He turned back to the approaching Trollocs. The Two Rivers men weren't making it easy for them to get up the incline. The men were running out of arrows, though.

pɛɹɪn hɛftəd mæhælaɪnɝ. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm fɛl sɑɹi tə beɪð ðə wɛpən ɪn blʌd soʊ sun æftɝ ɪts bɝθ, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɪm wɑz plizd. ðiz tʃɹɑləks, ən ðoʊz u lɛd ðɛm, hæd kɑz hɑpɝz dɛθ.

Perrin hefted Mah'alleinir. A part of him felt sorry to bathe the weapon in blood so soon after its birth, but the greater part of him was pleased. These Trollocs, and those who led them, had caused Hopper's death.

ə fɪst ə tʃɹɑləks kɹɛstəd ðə hɪltɑp, ə feɪd muvɪŋ ɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm, lɛd baɪ ənʌðɝ feɪd wɪð ə blæk sɔɹd. pɛɹɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɔɹ ən tʃɑɹdʒ fɔɹwɝd, hæmɝ hɛl haɪ.

A fist of Trollocs crested the hilltop, a Fade moving in behind them, led by another Fade with a black sword. Perrin let out a roar and charged forward, hammer held high.

* * * ɡɑləd kɝst, tɝnɪŋ staʊɾ ən tʃɑpɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd daʊn ɪndə ðə nɛk ə tʃɹɑlɑk wɪð ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə bɛɹ, dɑɹk, θɪk blʌd spɝɾɪd aʊɾ ɪn ə nɔɪsəm ɡʌʃ, bʌt ðə bists wɝ tɛɹəbli dɪfəkəl tə kɪl. ɡɑləd hæd hɝd ðə stɔɹiz, hæd tʃɹeɪnd wɪð mɛn u hæd fɔt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. stɪl, ðɛɹ ɹɪzɪliəns sɝpɹaɪz hɪm. hi hæd tə hæk ət ðə kɹitʃɝ θɹi mɔɹ taɪmz bɪfɔɹ ɪt dʒɹɑpt. ɔlɹɛɾi, ɡɑləɾ ɛs ɑɹm wɑz eɪkɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɪnɛs tə faɪɾɪŋ mɑnstɝz laɪk ðɪs. hi juz hɔɹsbæk sɔɹd fɔɹmz, bʌɾ ɔfən ðə moʊs dɝɛkt ən bɹuɾəl ə ðɛm. wʊdzmən stʃɹɪps ðə bɹæntʃ. ɑɹk ə ðə mun. stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə spɑɹk.

* * * Galad cursed, turning Stout and chopping his sword down into the neck of Trolloc with the head of a bear, Dark, thick blood spurted out in a noisome gush, but the beasts were terribly difficult to kill. Galad had heard the stories, had trained with men who had fought Shadowspawn. Still, their resilience surprised him. He had to hack at the creature three more times before it dropped. Already, Galad s arm was aching. There was no finesse to fighting monsters like this. He used horseback sword forms, but often the most direct and brutal of them. Woodsman Strips the Branch. Arc of the Moon. Striking the Spark.

hɪz mɛn wɝn fɛɹiŋ wɛl. ðeɪ wɝ bɑkst ɪn, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹum fəɹ lænsɪz. ðə sæliɪŋ ətæks hæd wɝk fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌt ðə hɛvi kævəlɹi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə ɹitʃɹit bæk tə ðə fʊt laɪnz, ən ɪz hoʊl fɔɹs wɑz biɪŋ pʊʃt ist. ði ɑmɑdɪʃənz wɝ biɪŋ oʊvɝwɛlmd, ən ðə fɔɹs ə ði ətæk wɑz tu ɡɹeɪt tə əlaʊ fɝðɝ kævəlɹi tʃɑɹdʒəz. ɔl ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɑn hɔɹsbæk kəd də wɑz swɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛpənz waɪldli ɪn ən ətɛmp tə steɪ əlaɪv.

His men weren't faring well. They were boxed in, and there was no longer room for lances. The sallying attacks had worked for a time, but the heavy cavalry had been forced to retreat back to the foot lines, and his whole force was being pushed east. The Amadicians were being overwhelmed, and the force of the attack was too great to allow further cavalry charges. All the Children on horseback could do was swing their weapons wildly in an attempt to stay alive.

ɡɑləd tɝn staʊt, bʌt tu snɑɹlɪŋ tʃɹɑləks lɛp fəɹ hɪm. hi kwɪkli tʊk wʌn əkɹɔs ðə nɛk wɪð hɛɹən snætʃɪz ði ɪlvɝnʃ, bʌt ðə kɹitʃɝ fɛl fɔɹwɝɾ ɑntu staʊt, kɑzɪŋ ðə hɔɹs tə lɝtʃ əweɪ. ənʌðɝ bɹut slæʃt ə kætʃpoʊl ət ðə hɔɹsəz nɛk. ðə hɔɹs fɛl.

Galad turned Stout, but two snarling Trollocs leaped for him. He quickly took one across the neck with Heron Snatches the Silvernsh, but the creature fell forward onto Stout, causing the horse to lurch away. Another brute slashed a catchpole at the horse's neck. The horse fell.

ɡɑləd bɛɹli mænədʒ tə θɹoʊ hɪmsɛlf fɹi, hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ə hip əz staʊt kəlæpst, lɛɡz dʒɝkɪŋ, nɛk spɝɾɪŋ blʌɾ əkɹɔs ɪz waɪt ʃoʊldɝ. ɡɑləd ɹoʊld, sɔɹd twɪstəd tə ðə saɪd, bʌɾ i hæd lændəd ɹɔŋ. hɪz æŋkəl ɹɛntʃt ɪn peɪn.

Galad barely managed to throw himself free, hitting the ground in a heap as Stout collapsed, legs jerking, neck spurting blood across his white shoulder. Galad rolled, sword twisted to the side, but he had landed wrong. His ankle wrenched in pain.

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə peɪn, hi bɹɔɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ʌp ɪn taɪm tə dɪflɛk ðə hʊk ʌv ə bɹaʊn-fɝd mɑnstɝ, naɪn fit tɔl, ðət stæŋk ə dɛθ. ɡɑlədz pɛɹi sɛn ɪm ɔf bæləns əɡɛn.

Ignoring the pain, he brought his sword up in time to deflect the hook of a brown-furred monster, nine feet tall, that stank of death. Galad's parry sent him off balance again.

"ɡɑləd!"

"Galad!"

fɪɡjɝz ɪn waɪt kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks. ɹikɪŋ blʌd spɹeɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ. waɪt fɪɡjɝz tʌmbəl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ dʒɹɪvən bæk. bɔɹnhəl stʊd pæntɪŋ, sɔɹɾ aʊt, ʃil dɛntɪɾ ən spɹeɪd wɪð dɑɹk blʌd. hi hæd fɔɹ mɛn wɪð hɪm. tu ʌðɝz hæd fɔlən.

Figures in white crashed into the Trollocs. Reeking blood sprayed in the air. White figures tumbled to the ground, but the Trollocs were driven back. Bornhald stood panting, sword out, shield dented and sprayed with dark blood. He had four men with him. Two others had fallen.

θæŋk ju," ɡɑləd sɛd. "jɔɹ maʊns?"

Thank you," Galad said. "Your mounts?"

kʌt daʊn," bɔɹnhəl sɛd. "ðeɪ mʌst əv ɔɹɾɝz tə ɡoʊ æftɝ ðə hɔɹsəz."

Cut down," Bornhald said. "They must have orders to go after the horses."

"doʊnt wɑn əs ɪskeɪpɪŋ," ɡɑləd sɛd. "ɔɹ ɹæliɪŋ ə tʃɑɹdʒ." hi ɡlæns daʊn ðə laɪn ə bɪliɡɝd soʊlʒɝz. twɛnti θaʊzən hæd simd ə ɡɹæn ɑɹmi, bʌt ðə bæɾəl laɪnz wɝ ə mɛs. ən ðə tʃɹɑləks kəntɪnjud tə kʌm, weɪv æftɝ weɪv. ðə nɔɹðɝn sɛkʃən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹənz laɪn wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ pʊʃɪŋ fɔɹwɝd ðəɹ wɪð ə pɪnsɝ muvmən sɝaʊnd ɡɑlədz fɔɹs.

"Don't want us escaping," Galad said. "Or rallying a charge." He glanced down the line of beleaguered soldiers. Twenty thousand had seemed a grand army, but the battle lines were a mess. And the Trollocs continued to come, wave after wave. The northern section of the Children's line was breaking, and the Trollocs were pushing forward there with a pincer movement surround Galad's force.

ðeɪd kʌɾ əm ɔf ɑn ðə nɔɹθ ən saʊθ tə ɹæm əm əɡɛns ðə hɪl. laɪt!

They'd cut them off on the north and south to ram them against the hill. Light!

"ɹæli tə ðə nɔɹðɝn fʊt laɪn!" ɡɑləd jɛld. hi ɹæn ɪn ðət dɝək-ʃən əz kwɪkli əz i kʊd, hɪz æŋkəl pɹətɛstɪŋ, bʌt stɪl fʌŋkʃənɪŋ. mɛn dʒɔɪnd wɪð hɪm. ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ waɪt.

"Rally to the northern foot line!" Galad yelled. He ran in that direc-tion as quickly as he could, his ankle protesting, but still functioning. Men joined with him. Their clothing was no longer white.

ɡɑləd nu ðət moʊs dʒɛnɝəlz, laɪk ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn, dɪdn faɪɾ ɑn ðə fɹʌn laɪnz. ðeɪ wɝ tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ ðæt, ən ðɛɹ maɪnz wɝ niɾəd fəɹ ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ ðə faɪt. pɝhæps ðət wɑz wʌt ɡɑləd ʃʊɾə dʌn ɪt wɑz fɔlɪŋ əpɑɹt.

Galad knew that most generals, like Gareth Bryne, didn't fight on the front lines. They were too important for that, and their minds were needed for organizing the fight. Perhaps that was what Galad should have done It was falling apart.

hɪz mɛn wɝ ɡʊd. sɑləd. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst wɪð tʃɹɑləks oʊnli naʊ - tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ əkɹɔs mʌɾi ɡɹaʊn ɑn ə dɑɹk naɪt, lɪt baɪ ɡlɑbz hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ - dɪɾ i si haʊ ɪnɪkspɪɹiəns mɛni ʌv əm wɝ. hi hæd səm vɛɾɝənz, bʌt ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ɡɹup hæd fɔt moʊsli əɡɛnst ənɹuli bændəts əɹ sɪɾi məlɪʃəz.

His men were good. Solid. But they were inexperienced with Trollocs Only now - charging across muddy ground on a dark night, lit by globes hanging in the air - did he see how inexperienced many of them were. He had some veterans, but the larger group had fought mostly against unruly bandits or city militias.

ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ dɪfɹənt. ðə haʊlɪŋ, ɡɹʌntɪŋ, snɑɹlɪŋ mɑnstɝz wɝ ɪn ə fɹɛnzi. wʌt ðeɪ lækt ɪn mɪlətɛɹi dɪsəplən ðeɪ meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ ən fɝɑsəɾi. ən hʌŋɡɝ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl əmɪɾ əm wɝ tɛɹəbəl ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪk ə fɔɹmeɪʃən ɔl ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn. ɡɑlədz soʊlʒɝz wɝ bʌklɪŋ.

The Trollocs were different. The howling, grunting, snarling monsters were in a frenzy. What they lacked in military discipline they made up for in strength and ferocity. And hunger. The Myrddraal amid them were terrible enough to break a formation all on their own. Galad's soldiers were buckling.

"hoʊld!" ɡɑləd bɛloʊd, ɹitʃɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ sɛkʃən ə ðə laɪn. hi hæɾ ɔɹnhæfd ən əbaʊt fɪfti mɛn. nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf. "wi ɑɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt! wi də nɑt ɡɪv bɪfɔɹ ðə ʃædoʊ!"

"Hold!" Galad bellowed, reaching the breaking section of the line. He had Bornhafd and about fifty men. Not nearly enough. "We are the Children of the Light! We do not give before the Shadow!"

ɪt dɪdnt wɝk. wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dɪzæstɝ pleɪ aʊt, hɪz ɪntaɪɝ fɹeɪmwɝk ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ stɑɹɾəd tə kɹæk. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɝ nɑt pɹətɛktəd baɪ ðɛɹ ɡʊdnəs; ðeɪ wɝ fɔlɪŋ ɪn swɑθs, laɪk ɡɹeɪn bɪfɔɹ ðə saɪð. wɝs ðən ðæt, səm dɪd nɑt faɪt væljənli əɹ hoʊld wɪð ɹizɑlv. tu mɛni jɛld ɪn tɛɹɝ, ɹʌnɪŋ. ði ɑmɑdɪʃənz i kəɾ ʌndɝstænd, bʌɾ ə lɑɾ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ.

It didn't work. Watching the disaster play out, his entire framework of understanding started to crack. The Children of the Light were not protected by their goodness; they were falling in swaths, like grain before the scythe. Worse than that, some did not fight valiantly or hold with resolve. Too many yelled in terror, running. The Amadicians he could understand, but a lot of the Children themselves were little better.

ðeɪ wɝn kaʊɝdz. ðeɪ wɝn pʊɹ faɪɾɝz. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs mɛn. ævɝɪdʒ. ðət wɑzn haʊ ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə bi.

They weren't cowards. They weren't poor fighters. They were just men. Average. That wasn't how it was supposed to be.

θʌndɝ saʊndəɾ əz ɡælɛn bɹɔɾ ɪz hɔɹsmən ɝaʊn ɪn ənʌðɝ tʃɑɹdʒ. ðeɪ hæmɝɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk laɪn ən fɔɹs mɛni ʌv əm ɔf ði ɛdʒ, tʌmbəlɪŋ əm bæk daʊn ði ɪnklaɪn.

Thunder sounded as Gallenne brought his horsemen around in another charge. They hammered into the Trolloc line and forced many of them off the edge, tumbling them back down the incline.

pɛɹɪn slæmd mæbɔlaɪnɝ ɪndə ə tʃɹɑləks hɛd. ðə fɔɹs ə ðə bloʊ tɔs ðə kɹitʃɝ tə ðə saɪd, ən - ɑdli - ɪts skɪn sɪzəld ən smoʊkt wɛɹ ðə hæmɝ hæd hɪt. ðɪs hæpənd wɪð itʃ bloʊ, əz ɪf ðə tʌtʃ ə mæhælaɪnɝ bɝn ðɛm, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn fɛlt oʊnli ə kʌmfɝt-eɪbəl wɔɹmθ fɹəm ðə hæmɝ.

Perrin slammed Mab'alleinir into a Trollocs head. The force of the blow tossed the creature to the side, and - oddly - its skin sizzled and smoked where the hammer had hit. This happened with each blow, as if the touch of Mah'alleinir burned them, though Perrin felt only a comfort-able warmth from the hammer.

ɡælɛnz tʃɑɹdʒ pʌntʃt θɹu ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹæŋks, sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ əm ɪndə tu koʊhɔɹts, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni kɑɹkəsɪz ɪt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ dɪfəkəl fəɹ ɪz lænsɝz tə tʃɑɹdʒ. ɡælɛn wɪθdʒɹu ən ə kəntɪnʒənt ə tu ɹɪv- ɝz mɛn muvd ɪn ən ʃɑɾ æɹoʊz ət ðə tʃɹɑləks, kʌɾɪŋ əm daʊn ɪn ə weɪv ə skɹimɪŋ, haʊlɪŋ, ɹikɪŋ dɛθ.

Gallenne's charge punched through the Trolloc ranks, separating them into two cohorts, but there were so many carcasses it was getting difficult for his lancers to charge. Gallenne withdrew and a contingent of Two Riv- ers men moved in and shot arrows at the Trollocs, cutting them down in a wave of screaming, howling, reeking death.

pɛɹɪn pʊl stɛpɝ bæk, fʊt soʊlʒɝz fɔɹmɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. vɛɹi fju ʌv ɪz mɛn hæd fɔlən əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks. ʌv kɔɹs, ivən wʌn wɑz tu mɛni.

Perrin pulled Stepper back, foot soldiers forming around him. Very few of his men had fallen among the Trollocs. Of course, even one was too many.

ɑɹɡændə tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp ɑn ɪz hɔɹs. hid lɔst ɪz hɛlməts plumz sʌmwɛɹ, bʌt wɑz smaɪlɪŋ bɹɔdli. "aɪv ɹɛɹli hæd sətʃ ə plizɪŋ bæɾəl, eɪ-bɑɹə," hi sɛd. "ɛnəmiz tə fɛl ðət jə nid nɑt fil ə stɪŋ ə pɪɾi fɔɹ, ə pɝfək steɪdʒɪŋ ɛɹiə ən dɪfɛnsəbəl pəzɪʃən. ɑɹtʃɝz tə dʒɹim ʌv ən æʃəmən tə stɑp ðə ɡæps! aɪv leɪd daʊn oʊvɝ tu dʌzən ə ðə bists maɪsɛlf. fəɹ ðɪs deɪ əloʊn, aɪm ɡlæd wi fɑloʊd ju!"

Arganda trotted up on his horse. He'd lost his helmet's plumes somewhere, but was smiling broadly. "I've rarely had such a pleasing battle, Ay-bara," he said. "Enemies to fell that you need not feel a sting of pity for, a perfect staging area and defensible position. Archers to dream of and Asha'man to stop the gaps! I've laid down over two dozen of the beasts myself. For this day alone, I'm glad we followed you!"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. hi dɪdn pɔɪn aʊt ðət wʌn ə ðə ɹizənz ðeɪ wɝ hævɪŋ ən izi taɪm ʌv ɪt wɑz ðət moʊst ə ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ foʊkəst ɑn ðə waɪtkloʊks. tʃɹɑləks wɝ næsti, mɑnstʃɹəs θɪŋz, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ə fɪɹsli sɛlfɪʃ stʃɹik. tʃɑɹdʒ ʌp ðə hɪlsaɪɾ ət bɔlz ə faɪɝ ən lɔŋbaʊmən, oʊnli tə tʃɹaɪ ən siz ɡɹaʊn fɹəm tu fʊl kəntɪnʒənts ə kævəlɹi? bɛɾɝ tə sik ði iziɝ foʊ, ən ɪt meɪd tæktɪkəl sɛns, tu. foʊkəs ɑn ði iziɝ bæɾəl fɝst, wən jə hæd tu fɹʌns tə faɪɾ ɑn.

Perrin nodded. He didn't point out that one of the reasons they were having an easy time of it was that most of the Trollocs were focused on the Whitecloaks. Trollocs were nasty, monstrous things, and they had a fiercely selfish streak. Charge up the hillside at balls of fire and longbowmen, only to try and seize ground from two full contingents of cavalry? Better to seek the easier foe, and it made tactical sense, too. Focus on the easier battle first, when you had two fronts to fight on.

ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɹʌʃ ðə waɪtkloʊks bæk əɡɛns ðə hɪlsaɪɾ əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl, ən hæd swɔɹm ðɛm, nɑt livɪŋ əm ɹum tə ɹaɪd ðɛɹ kævəlɹi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒəz, sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ ɡɹups ə ðɛm.

They were trying to crush the Whitecloaks back against the hillside as quickly as possible, and had swarmed them, not leaving them room to ride their cavalry in charges, separating groups of them.

ðə pɝsən liɾɪŋ ðɪs ʌndɝstʊd tæktɪks; ðɪs wɑzn ðə wɝk ə tʃɹɑlɑk maɪnz.

The person leading this understood tactics; this wasn't the work of Trolloc minds.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn!" dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝz vɔɪs ɹoʊz əbʌv ðə dɪn ə haʊlɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. hi skɹæmbəld ʌp tə stɛpɝz saɪd. "ju æsk mi tə wɑtʃ ən tɛl jə haʊ ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. wɛl, jəl wɑnə lʊk, meɪbi."

"Lord Perrin!" Jori Congar's voice rose above the din of howling Trollocs. He scrambled up to Stepper's side. "You asked me to watch and tell you how they were doing. Well, you'll want to look, maybe."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz fɪst, ðən meɪkɪŋ ə tʃɑpɪŋ moʊʃən. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil stʊd bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɑn ə ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃən ðət kəd lʊk daʊn təwɔɹd ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ðɛɹ meɪn ɔɹɾɝz wɝ tə teɪk daʊn ɛni mɹdʒɹɑl ðeɪ spɑɾəd. pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə kip əz mɛni ʌv ðoʊz θɪŋz əz pɑsəbəl ɔf ðə haɪts; ɪt kəd kɑs dʌzənz ə laɪvz tə kɪl ə sɪŋɡəl mɹdʒɹɑl wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ əɹ æks. bɛs tə kɪl wɪð faɪɝ, fɹəm ə dɪstəns. bɪsaɪdz, səmtaɪmz kɪlɪŋ wʌn ə ðə feɪdz wəd min kɪlɪŋ ə kɑmpləmən ə tʃɹɑləks lɪŋk tə ɪt.

Perrin nodded, raising his fist, then making a chopping motion. Grady and Neald stood behind him, on a rock formation that could look down toward the roadway. Their main orders were to take down any Myrddraal they spotted. Perrin wanted to keep as many of those things as possible off the heights; it could cost dozens of lives to kill a single Myrddraal with the sword or axe. Best to kill with Fire, from a distance. Besides, sometimes killing one of the Fades would mean killing a complement of Trollocs linked to it.

ði æʃəmən, ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz sɔ pɛɹɪnz sɪɡnəl. ðeɪ bɪɡæn ə fʊl əsɔlt ɑn ðə tʃɹɑləks, faɪɝ flaɪɪŋ fɹəm hænz, laɪtnɪŋ blæstɪŋ fɹəm ðə skaɪ, pʊʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks bæk daʊn ði ɪnklaɪn. pɛɹɪnz fəɹ soʊlʒɝz pʊl bæk fəɹ ə fju moʊməns' ɹɛst.

The Asha'man, Aes Sedai and Wise Ones saw Perrin's signal. They began a full assault on the Trollocs, fire flying from hands, lightning blasting from the sky, pushing the Trollocs back down the incline. Perrin's for soldiers pulled back for a few moments' rest.

pɛɹɪn nʌdʒ stɛpɝ tə ði ɛdʒ, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp tə ðə saʊθ, hoʊldɪŋ mæhælaɪnɝ daʊn baɪ hɪz lɛɡ. bɪloʊ, dəmədʒɹdz fɔɹs wɑz duɪŋ ivən wɝs ðən pɛɹɪn hæd wɝid. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd dʒɹɪl fɔɹ-wɔɹd, nɪɹli dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ðə waɪtkloʊks ɪndə tu sɛkʃənz. ðə mɑnstɝz wɝ sɝdʒɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə saɪdz, ɛntʃɹæpɪŋ ɡɑləd, meɪkɪŋ ðə waɪtkloʊks faɪɾ ɑn θɹi fɹʌns. ðɛɹ bæks wɝ tə ðə hɪlsaɪd, ən mɛni ɡɹups ə kævəlɹi hæd bɪn kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə meɪn bɑɾi ʌv faɪɾɪŋ.

Perrin nudged Stepper to the edge, looking down the slope to the south, holding Mah'alleinir down by his leg. Below, Damodred's force was doing even worse than Perrin had worried. The Trollocs had drilled for-ward, nearly dividing the Whitecloaks into two sections. The monsters were surging around the sides, entrapping Galad, making the Whitecloaks fight on three fronts. Their backs were to the hillside, and many groups of cavalry had been cut off from the main body of fighting.

ɡælɛn tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn. "ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ stɪl əpɪɹɪŋ. aɪd ɡɛs fɪfti θaʊzən ə ðə bists soʊ fɑɹ. ði æʃəmən seɪ ðeɪv oʊnli sɛns ðə wʌn tʃænlɝ, ən i ɪzən ɛnɡeɪdʒɪŋ."

Gallenne trotted up beside Perrin. "The Trollocs are still appearing. I'd guess fifty thousand of the beasts so far. The Asha'man say they've only sensed the one channeler, and he isn't engaging."

"ðə wʌn liɾɪŋ ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn woʊnt wɑnə kəmɪt ðɛɹ tʃæn-nɛlɝz," pɛɹɪn ɡɛst.

"The one leading the Shadowspawn won't want to commit their chan-nelers," Perrin guessed.

"nɑt wɪð əs hævɪŋ ðə haɪ ɡɹaʊnd. ðəl liv ðə tʃɹɑləks tə də wʌt dæmədʒ ðeɪ kæn, ən si ɪf ðeɪ ɡeɪn ði ʌpɝ hænd. ɪf ðeɪ du, wɪl si tʃænlɝz kʌm aʊt."

"Not with us having the high ground. They'll leave the Trollocs to do what damage they can, and see if they gain the upper hand. If they do, we will see channelers come out."

ɡælɛn nɑɾəd.

Gallenne nodded.

"dəmədʒɹdz fɔɹs ɪz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl."

"Damodred's force is in trouble."

"jɛs," ɡælɛn sɛd. "ju pəzɪʃən əs wɛl tə hɛlp ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹz wi wɝn ɪnʌf."

"Yes," Gallenne said. "You positioned us well to help them, but it appears we weren't enough."

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn fəɹ ðɛm," pɛɹɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd. hi pɔɪntəd. "ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm, bɑksɪŋ ɪm ɪn əɡɛns ðə hɪlsaɪd. wi kəd swip daʊn ən sɝpɹaɪz ðə bists wɪð ə bɹɔdsaɪd, bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ən fɹiɪŋ dəmədʒɹdz mɛn tə ɡɛt ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp ɑn ðə plætoʊ hɪɹ."

"I'm going down for them," Perrin decided. He pointed. "The Trollocs are surrounding him, boxing him in against the hillside. We could sweep down and surprise the beasts with a broadside, breaking through and freeing Damodred's men to get themselves up on the plateau here."

ɡælɛn fɹaʊnd. "pɑɹɾən, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ aɪ mʌst æsk. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt ðət jə fil jə oʊ ðɛm? aɪ wʊɾə sɑɹoʊɾ ɪf, ɪndid, wid kʌm hɪɹ tə ətæk əm - ðoʊ aɪ wʊɾə sin ɪts lɑdʒɪk.

Gallenne frowned. "Pardon, Lord Perrin, but I must ask. What is it that you feel you owe them? I would have sorrowed if, indeed, we'd come here to attack them - though I would have seen its logic.

bʌɾ aɪ si noʊ ɹizən tə hɛlp ðɛm."

But I see no reason to help them."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. "ɪts dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə du."

Perrin grunted. "It's just the right thing to do."

"ðæɾ ɪz ə sʌbʒɪkt ə dəbeɪt," ɡælɛn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛlməɾɪd hɛd. "faɪɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz ɪz ɛksələnt, fəɹ ɛvɹi wʌn ðət fɔlz ɪz wʌn fjuɝ tə feɪs ət ðə læs bæɾəl. əɹ mɛn ɡɛt pɹæktəs faɪɾɪŋ ðɛm, ən kən lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ fɪɹz. bʌt ðət sloʊp ɪz stip ən tʃɹɛtʃɝəs; ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə ɹaɪd daʊn tə dəmədʒɹd, jə kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ əɹ ædvæntɪdʒ.

"That is a subject of debate," Gallenne said, shaking his helmeted head. "Fighting the Trollocs and Fades is excellent, for every one that falls is one fewer to face at the Last Battle. Our men get practice fighting them, and can learn to control their fears. But that slope is steep and treacherous; if you try to ride down to Damodred, you could destroy our advantage.

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniweɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "dʒɔɹi, ɡoʊ ɡɛt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ən ði æʃəmən. əl niɾ əm tə sɑfən ðə tʃɹɑləks fəɹ maɪ tʃɑɹdʒ." hi lʊk daʊn əɡɛn. mɛmɹiz ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz flʌɾəd ɪz maɪnd. blʌd. dɛθ. mæhælaɪnɝ ɡɹu wɔɹmɝ ɪn ɪz fɪst. "aɪ woʊn liv əm tə ɪt, ɡæl- lɛn. nɑɾ ivən ðɛm. wɪl jə dʒɔɪn mi?"

"I'm going anyway," Perrin said. "Jori, go get the Two Rivers men and the Asha'man. I'll need them to soften the Trollocs for my charge." He looked down again. Memories of the Two Rivers flooded his mind. Blood. Death. Mah'alleinir grew warmer in his fist. "I won't leave them to it, Gal- lenne. Not even them. Will you join me?"

"ju ɑɹ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ mæn, eɪbɑɹə." ɡælɛn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ænd wʌn ə tʃɹu ɑnɝ. jɛs, aɪ wɪl."

"You are a strange man, Aybara." Gallenne hesitated. "And one of true honor. Yes, I will."

"ɡʊd. dʒɔɹi, ɡɛt muvɪŋ. wi mʌst ɹitʃ dəmədʒɹd bɪfɔɹ ɪz laɪnz bɹeɪk."

"Good. Jori, get moving. We must reach Damodred before his lines break."

ə ʃɑk ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə mæs ə tʃɹɑləks. ɡɑləd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, sɔɹd ɹɪpt ɪn swɛɾi fɪŋɡɝz.

a shock rippled through the mass of Trollocs. Galad hesitated, sword ripped in sweaty fingers.

hɪz ɪntaɪɝ bɑɾi ætʃt. moʊnz keɪm fɹəm ɔl ɹaʊn hɪm, səm ɡʌɾɝəl ən snɑɹlɪŋ - tʃɹɑləks daɪɪŋ  - səm pɪɾiəs fɹəm fɔlən mɛn. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən nɪɹ ɪm wɝ hoʊldɪŋ. bɛɹli.

His entire body ached. Moans came from all round him, some guttural and snarling - Trollocs dying  - some piteous from fallen men. The Children near him were holding. Barely.

ðə naɪt wɑz dɪm, ivən wɪð ðoʊz laɪts. ɪt fɛlt laɪk faɪɾɪŋ naɪtmɛɹz. bʌɾ ɪf ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt kəd nɑt stæn əɡɛns dɑɹknəs, hu kʊd?

The night was dim, even with those lights. It felt like fighting nightmares. But if the Children of the Light could not stand against darkness, who could?

ðə tʃɹɑləks bɪɡæn haʊlɪŋ mɔɹ laʊdli. ðoʊz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm tɝnd, spikɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ə kɹud, snɑɹlɪŋ tʌŋ ðət kɑzd ɪm tə pʊl bæk ɪn ɹɪvʌlʃən. tʃɹɑləks kəd spik? hi hædnt noʊn ðæt. wʌt hæd dʒɹɔn ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən?

The Trollocs began howling more loudly. Those in front of him turned, speaking to one another in a crude, snarling tongue that caused him to pull back in revulsion. Trollocs could speak? He hadn't known that. What had drawn their attention?

ən ðən i sɔ ɪt. ə heɪl ʌv æɹoʊz, fɔlɪŋ fɹəm əbʌv, ɹɪpt ɪndə ɹæŋks ə ðə nɪɹbaɪ tʃɹɑləks.

And then he saw it. A hail of arrows, falling from above, ripped into ranks of the nearby Trollocs.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz boʊmən lɪvd ʌp tə ðɛɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. ɡɑləd wʊdn əv tʃɹʌstɪd moʊst ɑɹtʃɝz tə ʃut laɪk ðæt, nɑt wɪθaʊt stʃɹeɪ æɹoʊz fɔlɪŋ ɑn ðə waɪtkloʊks. ðiz ɑɹtʃɝz wɝ pɹɪsaɪs, haʊɛvɝ.

The Two Rivers bowmen lived up to their reputation. Galad wouldn't have trusted most archers to shoot like that, not without stray arrows falling on the Whitecloaks. These archers were precise, however.

ðə tʃɹɑləks skɹimd ən haʊld. ðɛn, fɹəm ðə tɑp ə ðə ɹaɪz, ə θaʊzən hɔɹsmən tʃɑɹdʒd.

The Trollocs screamed and howled. Then, from the top of the rise, a thousand horsemen charged.

laɪts flæʃt ɝaʊn ðɛm; faɪɝz fɛl fɹəm əbʌv, ɑɹsɪŋ daʊn laɪk ɹɛd-ɡoʊldən lænsɪz. ðeɪ ɪluməneɪɾəd ðə hɔɹsmən ɪn sɪlvɝ.

Lights flashed around them; fires fell from above, arcing down like red-golden lances. They illuminated the horsemen in silver.

ɪt wɑz ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl mənuvɝ. ði ɪnklaɪn wɑz stip ɪnʌf ðət hɔɹsəz kəɾ əv tʃɹɪpt, fɔlən, tʌmbəl ði ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹs ɪndə ə jusləs mæs ə bɑɾiz. bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn fɔl. ðeɪ ɡæləpt ʃʊɹ- fʊɾɪd, lænsɪz ɡlimɪŋ. ən ət ðɛɹ fɹʌn ɹoʊɾ ə bɪɹɾəd mɑnstɝ ʌv ə mæn wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ hæmɝ hɛl haɪ. pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə hɪmsɛlf, əbʌv ɪz hɛɾ ə bænɝ flæpɪŋ, kæɹid baɪ ə mæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒʌs bɪhaɪnd.

It was an incredible maneuver. The incline was steep enough that horses could have tripped, fallen, tumbled the entire force into a useless mass of bodies. But they didn't fall. They galloped sure- footed, lances gleaming. And at their front rode a bearded monster of a man with a large hammer held high. Perrin Aybara himself, above his head a banner flapping, carried by a man riding just behind.

ðə kɹɪmzən wʊlfhɛd.

The crimson wolfhead.

dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, ɡɑləd loʊɝɾ ɪz ʃild ət ðə saɪt. eɪbɑɹə ɔlmoʊst simd əfleɪm fɹəm ðə tʌŋz ə faɪɝ ðət sɝaʊndəd hɪm. ɡɑləd kəd si ðoʊz waɪd, ɡoʊldən aɪz. laɪk faɪɝz ðɛmsɛlvz.

Despite himself, Galad lowered his shield at the sight. Aybara almost seemed aflame from the tongues of fire that surrounded him. Galad could see those wide, golden eyes. Like fires themselves.

ðə hɔɹsmən kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks ðət hæd sɝaʊndəd ɡɑlədz fɔɹs. eɪbɑɹə lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɔɹ oʊvɝ ðə dɪn, ðən bɪɡæn tə leɪ əbaʊɾ ɪm wɪð ðə hæmɝ. ði ətæk fɔɹs ðə tʃɹɑləks bæk.

The horsemen crashed into the Trollocs that had surrounded Galad's force. Aybara let out a roar over the din, then began to lay about him with the hammer. The attack forced the Trollocs back.

əsɔlt!" ɡɑləd jɛld. "pɹɛs ði ətæk! fɔɹs əm ɪndə ðə kævəlɹi!" hi tʃɑɹdʒ nɔɹθwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə feɪs ə ðə haɪts, bɔɹnhəld əɾ ɪz saɪd.

Assault!" Galad yelled. "Press the attack! Force them into the cavalry!" He charged northward, toward the face of the heights, Bornhald at his side.

nɪɹbaɪ, tʃɹɑm ɹælid wʌt wɑz lɛft ə hɪz lidʒən ən bɹɔɾ ɪɾ ɝaʊn tə ətæk ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑpəzəɾ eɪbɑɹə.

Nearby, Trom rallied what was left of his legion and brought it around to attack the Trollocs opposite Aybara.

ðə fɹeɪ ɡɹu ɪnkɹisɪŋli keɪɑɾɪk. ɡɑləd fɔt fjʊɹiəsli. əbʌv, ɪn-kɹɛɾəbli, eɪbɑɹəz ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi pɔɹd daʊn ði ɪnklaɪn, ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ðə haɪ ɡɹaʊnd. ðeɪ fɛl əpɑn ðə tʃɹɑləks, tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ə mɛn jɛlɪŋ. "ɡoʊldeɪniz! ɡoʊldeɪniz!"

The fray grew increasingly chaotic. Galad fought furiously. Above, in-credibly, Aybara's entire army poured down the incline, giving up the high ground. They fell upon the Trollocs, tens of thousands of men yelling. "Goldeneyes! Goldeneyes!"

ði ətæk pʊt ɡɑləɾ ən bɔɹnhəld ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks' ɹæŋks. ðə kɹi-tʊɹz tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl bæk fɹəm eɪbɑɹə, sɝdʒɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz. ðə mɛn nɪɹ ɡɑləɾ ən bɔɹnhəld wɝ sun faɪɾɪŋ dɛspɝətli tə steɪ əlaɪv. ɡɑləd fɪnɪʃt ɔf ə tʃɹɑlɑk wɪð ɹɪbən ɪn ði ɛɹ, bʌt spʌn ən ɪm-daɪeɪtli faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ ə ɹæm-feɪs bəhiməθ tɛn fit tɔl. hɔɹnz kɝld ɝaʊn ðə saɪdz ʌv ɪts ɪnɔɹməs skwɛɹ feɪs, bʌt ði aɪz wɝ hjumən, ən ðə loʊɝ dʒɔ əz wɛl.

The attack put Galad and Bornhald into the Trollocs' ranks. The crea-tures tried to pull back from Aybara, surging in all directions. The men near Galad and Bornhald were soon fighting desperately to stay alive. Galad finished off a Trolloc with Ribbon in the Air, but spun and imme-diately found himself facing a ram-faced behemoth ten feet tall. Horns curled around the sides of its enormous square face, but the eyes were human, and the lower jaw as well.

ɡɑləd dʌkt wən ɪt swʌŋ ɪts kætʃpoʊl, ðən ɹæmd ɪz sɔɹɾ ʌp ɪndə ɪts ɡʌt. ðə kɹitʃɝ skɹimd, ən bɔɹnhəl hæmstʃɹəŋ ɪt fɹəm ðə saɪd.

Galad ducked when it swung its catchpole, then rammed his sword up into its gut. The creature screamed, and Bornhald hamstrung it from the side.

ɡɑləd jɛld ən lɛp bækwɝd, bʌɾ ɪz twɪstəɾ æŋkəl faɪnəli feɪl hɪm. ɪt ɡɑt kɑɾ ɪn ə klft ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ɡɑləd hɝɾ ə tɛɹəbəl snæp əz i fɛl.

Galad yelled and leaped backward, but his twisted ankle finally failed him. It got caught in a cleft in the ground, and Galad heard a terrible snap as he fell.

ðə daɪɪŋ mɑnstɝ kɹæʃt daʊn ɑn hɪm, pɪnɪŋ ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. peɪn ʃɑɾ ʌp ɪz lɛɡ, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt. hi dʒɹɑpt ɪz sɔɹd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃʌv ðə kɑɹkəs fɹi. bɔɹnhəld, swɛɹɪŋ, fɛndɪɾ ɔf ə tʃɹɑlɑk ðət hæd ðə snaʊɾ ʌv ə bɔɹ. ɪt meɪɾ ə hɔɹəd ɡɹʌntɪŋ saʊnd.

The dying monster crashed down on him, pinning him to the ground. Pain shot up his leg, but he ignored it. He dropped his sword, trying to shove the carcass free. Bornhald, swearing, fended off a Trolloc that had the snout of a boar. It made a horrid grunting sound.

ɡɑləd hivd ɔf ðə stɪŋkɪŋ kɑɹkəs. tə ðə saɪd, hi kəd si mɛn ɪn waɪt - tʃɹɑm, wɪð baɪɑɝ əɾ ɪz saɪd, faɪɾɪŋ dɛspɝətli tə ɹitʃ ɡɑləd. ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni tʃɹɑləks, ən ðoʊz tʃɪlʒɹən ɪmiɾiətli nɪɹbaɪ hæd moʊsli fɔlən.

Galad heaved off the stinking carcass. To the side, he could see men in white - Trom, with Byar at his side, fighting desperately to reach Galad. There were so many Trollocs, and those Children immediately nearby had mostly fallen.

ɡɑləd ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd dʒʌst əz ə maʊntəd fɪɡjɝ bɝs θɹu ðə ʃædoʊz ən tʃɹɑləks dʒʌs tə ðə nɔɹθ. eɪbɑɹə. hi ɹoʊɾ ʌp ən paʊndɪd ðət mæsɪv hæmɝ ə hɪz ɪndə ə bɔɹ tʃɹɑlɑk, sɛndɪŋ ɪt kɹæʃɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. eɪbɑɹə lɛpt ɔf ɪz hɔɹs əz bɔɹnhəl skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ tə hɛlp ɡɑləd tə hɪz fit.

Galad reached for his sword just as a mounted figure burst through the shadows and Trollocs just to the north. Aybara. He rode up and pounded that massive hammer of his into a boar Trolloc, sending it crashing to the ground. Aybara leaped off his horse as Bornhald scrambled over to help Galad to his feet.

"ju ɑɹ wundəd?" eɪbɑɹə æskt.

"You are wounded?" Aybara asked.

"maɪ æŋkəl," ɡɑləd sɛd.

"My ankle," Galad said.

"ɑn maɪ hɔɹs," eɪbɑɹə sɛd.

"On my horse," Aybara said.

ɡɑləd dɪdn pɹoʊtɛst; ɪt meɪd sɛns. hi dɪd, haʊɛvɝ, fil ɪmbɛɹəst əz bɔɹnhəl hɛlpt ɪm ʌp. eɪbɑɹəz mɛn fɪld ɪn ɝaʊn ðɛm, pʊʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks bæk. naʊ ðəɾ eɪbɑɹəz ɑɹmi hæd dʒɔɪn ðə fɹeɪ, ɡɑlədz mɛn wɝ ɹæliɪŋ.

Galad didn't protest; it made sense. He did, however, feel embarrassed as Bornhald helped him up. Aybara's men filled in around them, pushing the Trollocs back. Now that Aybara's army had joined the fray, Galad's men were rallying.

ɹʌʃɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp hæd bɪn ə deɪnʒɝəs ɡæmbəl, bʌɾ əz sun əz ɡɑləd wɑz əstʃɹaɪɾ eɪbɑɹəz hɔɹs, hi kəd si ðət ðə ɡæmbəl hæd wɝkt, ðə mæsɪv tʃɑɹdʒ hæd bɹoʊkən ðə tʃɹɑləks əpɑɹt, ən səm ɡɹups stɑɹɾəd fliɾɪŋ. tʌŋz ə fleɪm fɛl fɹəm əbʌv, bɝnɪŋ mɹdʒɹɑl ən dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪntaɪɝ fɪsts ə tʃɹɑləks lɪŋk tə ðɛm.

Rushing down the slope had been a dangerous gamble, but as soon as Galad was astride Aybara's horse, he could see that the gamble had worked, The massive charge had broken the Trollocs apart, and some groups started fleeting. Tongues of flame fell from above, burning Myrddraal and dropping entire fists of Trollocs linked to them.

ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə faɪɾɪŋ tə du, bʌt ðə taɪd wɑz tɝnɪŋ. eɪbɑɹəz fɔɹsɪz kɑɹvd aʊɾ ə sɛkʃən ɝaʊn ðɛɹ liɾɝ, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm - ən baɪ ɪkstɛnʃən ɡɑləd - səm bɹiðɪŋ ɹum tə kənsɪɾɝ ðə nɛkst steɪdʒ ə ði ətæk.

There was still a great deal of fighting to do, but the tide was turning. Aybara's forces carved out a section around their leader, giving him - and by extension Galad - some breathing room to consider the next stage of the attack.

ɡɑləd tɝn tə eɪbɑɹə, hu wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪð kin ivz. "aɪ əsum jə θɪŋk ðət seɪvɪŋ mi wɪl ɪnfluəns maɪ dɪsɪʒən əbaʊt jəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt," ɡɑləd sɛd.

Galad turned to Aybara, who was studying the Trollocs with keen eves. "I assume you think that saving me will influence my decision about your judgment," Galad said.

"ɪt hæd bɛɾɝ," eɪbɑɹə mʌɾɝd.

"It had better," Aybara muttered.

ɡɑləd ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ɪt wɑzn ðə ɹɪspɑns hid bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ. "maɪ mɛn faɪn ɪt səspɪʃəs ðət jə əpɪɹd soʊ sun bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks."

Galad raised an eyebrow. It wasn't the response he'd been expecting. "My men find it suspicious that you appeared so soon before the Trollocs."

"wɛl, ðeɪ kən θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɑnt," eɪbɑɹə sɛd. "aɪ daʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ aɪ seɪ wɪl tʃeɪnʒ ðɛɹ maɪnz. ɪn ə weɪ, ðɪs ɪz maɪ fɔlt. ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ hɪɹ tə kɪl mi; aɪ dʒʌst ɡɑɾ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd spɹɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɹæp. bi ɡlæɾ aɪ dɪdn liv jə tə ðɛm. jə waɪtkloʊks əv kɑz mi nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ ɡɹif əz ðeɪ hæv."

"Well, they can think that if they want," Aybara said. "I doubt anything I say will change their minds. In a way, this is my fault. The Trollocs were here to kill me; I just got away before they could spring their trap. Be glad I didn't leave you to them. You Whitecloaks have caused me nearly as much grief as they have."

ɑdli, ɡɑləd faʊn hɪmsɛlf smaɪlɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ɛɹ əbaʊt ðɪs pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. ə mæn kəɾ æsk fəɹ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪn ən ælaɪ.

Oddly, Galad found himself smiling. There was a straightforward air about this Perrin Aybara. A man could ask for little more in an ally.

ɑɹ wi ælaɪz, ðɛn? ɡɑləd θɔt, nɑɾɪŋ tə tʃɹɑm ən baɪɑɝ əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt. pɝhæps fəɹ naʊ. hi dɪd tʃɹʌst eɪbɑɹə. jɛs, pɝhæps ðəɹ wɝ mɛn ɪn ðə wɝld u wəd pʊt təɡɛðɝ ən ɪntʃɹəkət plɑt laɪk ðɪs wʌn, ɔl tə tʃɹɪk ɪz weɪ ɪndə ɡɑlədz feɪvɝ. vɑldə hæd bɪn laɪk ðæt.

Are we allies, then? Galad thought, nodding to Trom and Byar as they approached. Perhaps for now. He did trust Aybara. Yes, perhaps there were men in the world who would put together an intricate plot like this one, all to trick his way into Galad's favor. Valda had been like that.

eɪbɑɹə wɑznt. hi ɹɪli wɑz stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. ɪf hid wɑntəd ðə tʃɪlʒɹən aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ, hiɾ əv kɪld əm ən muvd ɑn.

Aybara wasn't. He really was straightforward. If he'd wanted the Children out of his way, he'd have killed them and moved on.

"ðɛn soʊ bi ɪt, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɡɑləd sɛd. "aɪ neɪm jəɹ pʌnɪʃmən hɪɹ, ðɪs naɪt, ət ðɪs moʊmənt."

"Then so be it, Perrin Aybara," Galad said. "I name your punishment here, this night, at this moment."

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪz kɑntəmpleɪʃən ə ðə bæɾəl laɪnz. "wʌt? naʊ?"

Perrin frowned, turning away from his contemplation of the battle lines. "What? Now?"

aɪ dim, əz pʌnɪʃmənt, ðət jə peɪ blʌd pɹaɪs tə ðə fæmliz ə ðə dɛd tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn ði əmaʊn ə faɪv hʌnʒɹəd kɹaʊnz. aɪ ɔlsoʊ ɔɹɾɝ jə tə fɹɾ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl wɪð ɔl ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ jə kən mʌstɝ. də ðiz θɪŋz, ən aɪ pɹənaʊns jə klɛnzd ʌv ɡɪlt."

I deem, as punishment, that you pay blood price to the families of the dead Children in the amount of five hundred crowns. I also order you to frght in the Last Battle with all the strength you can muster. Do these things, and I pronounce you cleansed of guilt."

ɪt wɑz ən ɑd taɪm fəɹ ɪm tə ɡɪv ðɪs pɹɑkləmeɪʃən, bʌɾ i hæd meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən. ðeɪ wəd stɪl faɪt, ən pɝhæps wʌn wəd fɔl. ɡɑləd wɑntəɾ eɪbɑɹə tə noʊ ðə dʒʌdʒmənt, ɪn keɪs.

It was an odd time for him to give this proclamation, but he had made his decision. They would still fight, and perhaps one would fall. Galad wanted Aybara to know the judgment, in case.

eɪbɑɹə stʌɾid hɪm, ðən nɑɾəd. "aɪ neɪm ðət fɛɹ, ɡɑləd dɑmoʊ-dʒɹɛd." hi hɛld ʌp ɪz hænd.

Aybara studied him, then nodded. "I name that fair, Galad Damo-dred." He held up his hand.

"kɹitʃɝ ə dɑɹknəs!" sʌmwʌn muv bɪhaɪn eɪbɑɹə. ə fɪɡjɝ, pʊl-ɪŋ fɹi hɪz sɔɹd. ə hɪs, ə flæʃ ə mɛɾəl. baɪɑɝz aɪz, əlaɪt wɪð æŋɡɝ. hid pəzɪʃən hɪmsɛlf ɹaɪt wɛɹ i kəd stʃɹaɪk eɪbɑɹə ɪn ðə bæk.

"Creature of darkness!" Someone moved behind Aybara. A figure, pull-ing free his sword. A hiss, a flash of metal. Byar's eyes, alight with anger. He'd positioned himself right where he could strike Aybara in the back.

eɪbɑɹə spʌn; ɡɑləd ɹeɪzd ɪz sɔɹd. boʊθ wɝ tu sloʊ.

Aybara spun; Galad raised his sword. Both were too slow.

bʌt jɹət baɪɑɝz bloʊ dɪd nɑt fɔl. hi stʊd wɪð ɪz wɛpən əpɹeɪzd, fɹoʊzən, blʌd dʒɹɪbəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz lɪps. hi fɛl tə hɪz niz, ðən flɑpt ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹaɪɾ əɾ eɪbɑɹəz fit.

But Jaret Byar's blow did not fall. He stood with his weapon upraised, frozen, blood dribbling from his lips. He fell to his knees, then flopped onto the ground right at Aybara's feet.

Bornhald looked at Aybara, eyes still hateful, then cleaned his sword and rammed it into its sheath. He walked away, toward the area where the wounded had been taken. The area around Galad and Aybara was increasingly safe, the Trollocs pushed back, more solid battle lines forming, made of Aybara's men and the remaining Children.

"aɪ kən - "

"I can - "

"ɛɡwin, jəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ðə weɪɾ ə ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf ɪz ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝz. lemi meɪk ɝeɪnʒmənts."

"Egwene, you're the Amyrlin Seat. The weight of the world itself is on your shoulders. Let me make arrangements."

vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛd. ʃi stɛpt aʊtsaɪd, wɛɹ sɪlviænə weɪɾəd - ʃi hæd wʌn ə hɝ ɡlaʊɝz fəɹ ɡɔɪn. ɛɡwin sɛn səm sɝvəns fəɹ ə bɛd fəɹ hɪm, ðən ʃi ən əɹ kipɝ muvd ɔf, ə pɛɹ ə tʃʌbnz soʊlʒɝz fɑloʊɪŋ.

Very well," she said. She stepped outside, where Silviana waited - she had one of her glowers for Gawyn. Egwene sent some servants for a bed for him, then she and her Keeper moved off, a pair of Chubain's soldiers following.

ɡɔɪn wʊɾə laɪk tə ɡoʊ wɪð hɝ. ðəɹ maɪt stɪl bi əsæsənz əbaʊt. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt tə sɛn ɪm tə slip. hi wɑz hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ əpɹaɪt. hi stʊɾ ɑn ənstɛɾi lɛɡz, ðən noʊɾəst ə laɪn ə ʃit-kʌvɝd bɑɾiz aʊtsaɪd. ðeɪ wʊdn bi ɹimuvd əntɪl sɪstɝz hæɾ ə tʃæns tə lʊk əm oʊvɝ. ɹaɪt naʊ, ɹɪndɪŋ mɛsænə - ən lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌðɝ əsæsənz - hæd bɪn mɔɹ pɹɛsɪŋ.

Gawyn would have liked to go with her. There might still be assassins about. Unfortunately, she was right to send him to sleep. He was having trouble remaining upright. He stood on unsteady legs, then noticed a line of sheet-covered bodies outside. They wouldn't be removed until sisters had a chance to look them over. Right now, rinding Mesaana - and looking for other assassins - had been more pressing.

ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ, hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə wɔk oʊvɝ ən pʊl bæk ðə ʃit, ɹɪvilɪŋ sɛlɑɹks ən mɑzoʊniz laɪfləs feɪsəz - sɛlɑɹks, ənfɔɹɾu-nætli, sɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz bɑɾi, sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ɪɾ ət ðə hɛk.

Gritting his teeth, he forced himself to walk over and pull back the sheet, revealing Celark's and Mazone's lifeless faces - Celark's, unfortu-nately, sitting beside his body, separated from it at the heck.

"ju dɪd wɛl, mɛn," hi sɛd. "aɪl si ðət jəɹ fæmliz noʊ ðət jə seɪv ðə laɪf ə ði æmɪɝlɪn." ɪt meɪɾ ɪm æŋɡɹi tə luz sətʃ ɡʊd mɛn.

"You did well, men," he said. "I'll see that your families know that you saved the life of the Amyrlin." It made him angry to lose such good men.

bɝn ðoʊz sintʃæn, hi θɔt. ɛɡwin ɪz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðɛm. sʌmθɪŋ nidz tə bi dʌn.

Burn those Seanchan, he thought. Egwene is right about them. Something needs to be done.

hi ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd, tə wɛɹ ðə θɹi əsæsənz leɪ bɪniθ ʃits ə ðɛɹ oʊn, blæk- slɪpɝd fit stɪkɪŋ aʊt ðə bɑɾəm. tu wɪmən ən ə mæn.

He glanced to the side, to where the three assassins lay beneath sheets of their own, black- slippered feet sticking out the bottom. Two women and a man.

/ wʌndɝ... hi θɔt, ðən kɹɔs tə wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ. ɡɑɹdz ɡlænst əɾ ɪm əz i pʊl bæk ðə ʃit, bʌt noʊbɑdi fɝbeɪd hɪm.

/ wonder... he thought, then crossed to where they lay. Guards glanced at him as he pulled back the sheet, but nobody forbade him.

ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝ izi tə pɪk aʊt, ðoʊ oʊnli kəz hid bɪn toʊld wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ.

The ter'angreal were easy to pick out, though only because he'd been told what to look for.

aɪdɛntɪkəl blæk stoʊn ɹɪŋz, wɔɹn ɑn ðə mɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝz ə ðɛɹ ɹaɪt hænz. ðə ɹɪŋz wɝ kɑɹvd ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə vaɪn wɪð θɔɹnz. əpɛɹənli nʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əm fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, ət lis nɑt jɛt.

Identical black stone rings, worn on the middle fingers of their right hands. The rings were carved in the shape of a vine with thorns. Apparently none of the Aes Sedai had recognized them for what they were, at least not yet.

ɡɔɪn slɪpt ɔl θɹi ɹɪŋz ɔf, ðən tʌkt əm ɪndə hɪz pɑkət.

Gawyn slipped all three rings off, then tucked them into his pocket.

læn kəd fil sʌmθɪŋ, ə dɪstɪŋk dɪfɝəns tə ði ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. hid ɡɹoʊn əkʌstəm tə ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðoʊz, ən ðə wʊmən ðeɪ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd.

Lan could feel something, a distinct difference to the emotions in the back of his mind. He'd grown accustomed to ignoring those, and the woman they represented.

leɪtli, ðoʊz ɪmoʊʃənz hæd tʃeɪnʒd. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, hi wɑz sɝɾən ðət nɪneɪiv hæd teɪkən ɪz bɑnd. hi kəɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪ hɝ baɪ ðə weɪ ʃi fɛlt. haʊ kəd wʌn nɑt noʊ hɝ, ðət sɛns ə pæʃən ən kaɪndnəs? ɪt fɛlt . . . ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl.

Lately, those emotions had changed. More and more, he was certain that Nynaeve had taken his bond. He could identify her by the way she felt. How could one not know her, that sense of passion and kindness? It felt . . . remarkable.

hi stɛɹd daʊn ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ɪt twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə hɪl bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹɾ ə dɪstɪŋktɪv fɔɹtʃɹəs əhɛd. ðə bɔɹɾɝ bɪtwin kændɝ ən ɝæfəl wɑz mɑɹk baɪ ðə sɪlvɝwəl kips, ə lɑɹdʒ fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən bɪlt ɑn tu saɪdz ə fɝtʃhən pæs. ɪt wɑz ən ɪkstʃɹimli ɪmpɹɛsɪv fɔɹtʃɹəs-ɹɪli tu ʌv ðɛm, itʃ wʌn bɪlt ʌp ðə stʃɹeɪt wɔl ə ðə nɛɹoʊ kænjənlaɪk pæs. laɪk tu saɪdz ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs dɔɹweɪ.

He stared down the roadway. It twisted around the side of a hill before turning straight toward a distinctive fortress ahead. The border between Kandor and Arafel was marked by the Silverwall Keeps, a large fortification built on two sides of Firchon Pass. It was an extremely impressive fortress-really two of them, each one built up the straight wall of the narrow canyonlike pass. Like two sides of an enormous doorway.

ɡɛɾɪŋ θɹu ðə pæs ɹikwaɪɝd tʃɹævlɪŋ ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl dɪstəns bi-twin lɑɹdʒ stoʊn wɔlz pɑkt wɪð æɹoʊslɪts, ən ɪt wəd bi ɪfɛktɪv ət stɑpɪŋ ɑɹmiz muvɪŋ ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən.

Getting through the pass required traveling a considerable distance be-tween large stone walls pocked with arrowslits, and it would be effective at stopping armies moving in either direction.

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ælaɪz, ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɝ. bʌt ðət dɪdn stɑp ði ɝæfɛlɪn fɹəm wɑntɪŋ ə naɪs fɔɹtʃɹəs blɑkɪŋ ðə weɪ ʌp tə ʃoʊl ɑɹbɛlə. kæmpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðət fɔɹtʃɹəs wɑz ə ɡæðɝɪŋ ə θaʊzənz ə pipəl, klʌstɝɾ ɪn smɔlɝ ɡɹups. ðə flæɡ ʌv mɔlkiɝ - ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn - flu oʊvɝ səm ə ðə ɡɹups. ʌðɝz flu flæɡz ə kændɝ əɹ ɝæfəl.

They were all allies, the Borderlanders were. But that didn't stop the Arafellin from wanting a nice fortress blocking the way up to Shol Arbela. Camped in front of that fortress was a gathering of thousands of people, clustered in smaller groups. The flag of Malkier - the Golden Crane - flew over some of the groups. Others flew flags of Kandor or Arafel.

""wɪtʃ ə jə bɹoʊk jəɹ oʊθ?" læn æskt, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət ðə kæɹəvæn.

""Which of you broke your oath?" Lan asked, looking back at the caravan.

ðə mɛn ðəɹ ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz.

The men there shook their heads.

"noʊbɑdi niɾəd tə bɹeɪk ɪz oʊθ," ændɪɹ sɛd. "wʌɾ ɛls wəd jə du? kʌt θɹu ðə bɹoʊkən lænz? ði ənkæp hɪlz? ɪts hɪɹ əɹ noʊwɛɹ. ðeɪ noʊ ðɪs. ən soʊ ðeɪ weɪt fəɹ ju."

"Nobody needed to break his oath," Andere said. "What else would you do? Cut through the Broken Lands? The Uncapped Hills? It is here or nowhere. They know this. And so they wait for you."

læn ɡɹaʊld. ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli tʃɹu. "wi ɑɹ ə kæɹəvæn," hi sɛd laʊdli. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɪf ɛni æsk, jə meɪ ədmɪt ðət wəɹ mɔlkɪɹi. jə meɪ seɪ jə weɪt fəɹ jəɹ kɪŋ. ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹuθ. jə meɪ nɑt mɛnʃən ðət juv faʊn hɪm."

Lan growled. It was probably true. "We are a caravan," he said loudly. "Remember, if any ask, you may admit that we are Malkieri. You may say you wait for your king. That is truth. You may not mention that you have found him."

ði ʌðɝz sim tʃɹʌbəld, bʌt ðeɪ meɪd noʊ əbdʒɛkʃən. læn lɛd ðə weɪ daʊn ðə sloʊp, ðɛɹ kæɹəvæn ə twɛnti wæɡənz, wɔɹhɔɹsɪz ən ətɛndəns fɑloʊɪŋ.

The others seemed troubled, but they made no objection. Lan led the way down the slope, their caravan of twenty wagons, warhorses and attendants following.

ðɪs wɑz wʌt hiɾ ɔlweɪz wɝid wəd hæpən. ɹikleɪmɪŋ mɔlkiɝ wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. ðeɪ wəd daɪ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ lɑɹdʒ ðɛɹ fɔɹs. ən əsɔlt? ɑn ðə blaɪt? ɹɪdɪkjələs.

This was what he'd always worried would happen. Reclaiming Malkier was impossible. They would die, no matter how large their force. An assault? On the Blight? Ridiculous.

hi kəd nɑɾ æsk ðəɾ ə ðɛm. hi kəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ðəɾ ə ðɛm. əz i kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, hi bɪkeɪm mɔɹ ɹɛzəlut. ðoʊz bɹeɪv mɛn, flaɪɪŋ ðoʊz flæɡz . . . ðeɪ ʃəd dʒɔɪn wɪð ðə ʃaɪnɝən fɔɹsɪz ən faɪɾ ɪn ə bæɾəl ðət mɛn sʌmθɪŋ. hi wəd nɑt teɪk ðɛɹ laɪvz.

He could not ask that of them. He could not allow that of them. As he continued down the road, he became more resolute. Those brave men, flying those flags . . . they should join with the Shienaran forces and fight in a battle that meant something. He would not take their lives.

dɛθ ɪz laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ . . . ɹɑkim hæd θɹoʊn ðəɾ əɾ ɪm sɛvɹəl taɪmz dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹaɪd. hi hæd fɑloʊd læn dɛkeɪdz əɡoʊ, dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ. duɾi ɪz hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən.

Death is lighter than a feather . . . Rakim had thrown that at him several times during their ride. He had followed Lan decades ago, during the Aiel War. Duty is heavier than a mountain.

læn wɑz nɑt ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm duɾi. hi wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪt. stɪl, saɪɾ ə ðə kæmps stɝɾ ɪz hɑɹɾ əz i ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə sloʊp, ðən ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd. ðə weɪɾɪŋ mɛn wɔɹ sɪmpəl wɔɹiɝz ɡɑɹb, hædɔɹi ɪn pleɪs, wɪmən mɑɹkt wɪð ə kɪsən ɑn ðɛɹ fɔɹhɛdz. səm ə ðə mɛn wɔɹ koʊts wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝz - ðə mɑɹk ə ðə ɹɔɪəl ɡɑɹɾ ə mɔlkiɝ. ðeɪ wʊɾə dɑn ðoʊz oʊnli ɪf ðɛɹ fɑðɝz əɹ ɡɹændfɑðɝz hæd sɝvd ɪn ðət ɡɑɹd.

Lan was not running from duty. He was running toward it. Still, sight of the camps stirred his heart as he reached the bottom of the slope, then rode forward. The waiting men wore simple warrior's garb, hadori in place, women marked with a ki'sain on their foreheads. Some of the men wore coats with the Golden Crown on the shoulders - the mark of the royal guard of Malkier. They would have donned those only if their fathers or grandfathers had served in that guard.

ɪt wɑz ə saɪt ðət wʊɾə meɪd bʌkɑmə kɹaɪ. hi hæd θɔt ðə mɔlkɪɹi ɡɔn əz ə pipəl, bɹoʊkən, ʃæɾɝd, əbzɔɹbd baɪ ʌðɝ neɪʃənz. jɛt hɪɹ ðeɪ wɝ, ɡæðɝɪŋ ət ðə feɪntəst wɪspɝ ʌv ə kɔl tə ɑɹmz. mɛni wɝ oʊldɝ - læn hæd bɪn bʌɾ ə beɪb wən ɪz kɪŋdəm fɛl, ən ðoʊz u ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət deɪ əz mɛn wəd naʊ bi ɪn ðɛɹ sɛvənθ əɹ eɪtθ dɛkeɪd. ðeɪ hæd ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl wɔɹiɝz, ən ðeɪd bɹɔt ðɛɹ sʌnz ən ɡɹændsʌnz.

It was a sight that would have made Bukama cry. He had thought the Malkieri gone as a people, broken, shattered, absorbed by other nations. Yet here they were, gathering at the faintest whisper of a call to arms. Many were older - Lan had been but a babe when his kingdom fell, and those who remembered that day as men would now be in their seventh or eighth decade. They had gray hair, but they were still warriors, and they'd brought their sons and grandsons.

"teɪʃɝ mɔlkiɝ!" ə mæn kɹaɪɾ əz lænz ɡɹup pæst. ðə kɔl wɛn ʌp ə dʌzən, tu dʌzən taɪmz əz ðeɪ sɔ hɪz hædɔɹi. nʌn sim tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪm fəɹ u hi wɑz. ðeɪ əsum ðəɾ i hæd kʌm fəɹ ðə ɹizən ðeɪ hæd kʌm.

"Tai'shar Malkier!" a man cried as Lan's group passed. The call went up a dozen, two dozen times as they saw his hadori. None seemed to recognize him for who he was. They assumed that he had come for the reason they had come.

ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmz, læn θɔt. mʌst aɪ dɪnaɪ ðɛm ðə ɹaɪt tə faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd mi?

The Last Battle comes, Lan thought. Must I deny them the right to fight alongside me?

jɛs, hi mʌst. bɛst i pæst ənnoʊɾɪst ən ənɹɛkəɡnaɪzd. hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz fɔɹwɝd, hɪz hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, hɪz maʊθ kloʊzd. bʌɾ itʃ kɔl ə teɪʃɝ mɔlkiɝ meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə sɪɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ.

Yes, he must. Best he passed unnoticed and unrecognized. He kept his eyes forward, his hand on his sword, his mouth closed. But each call of Tai'shar Malkier made him want to sit up straighter.

itʃ sim tə stʃɹɛŋθən hɪm, pʊʃ ɪm fɔɹwɝd.

Each seemed to strengthen him, push him forward.

ðə ɡeɪts bɪtwin ðə tu fɔɹtʃɹəs kips wɝ oʊpən, ðoʊ soʊlʒɝz tʃɛkt ɛvɹi mæn u wɛn θɹu. læn hɔltəd mændɑɹb, ən ɪz pipəl stɑp bɪhaɪn hɪm. kəd ði ɝæfɛlɪn əv ɔɹɾɝz tə wɑtʃ fəɹ hɪm? wʌɾ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs dɪɾ i hæv bʌt tə ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd? ɡoʊɪŋ ɝaʊnd wəd teɪk wiks. hɪz kæɹəvæn weɪɾəd ɪts tɝn, ðən stɛpt ʌp tə ðə ɡɑɹd poʊst.

The gates between the two fortress keeps were open, though soldiers checked every man who went through. Lan halted Mandarb, and his people stopped behind him. Could the Arafellin have orders to watch for him? What other choice did he have but to go forward? Going around would take weeks. His caravan waited its turn, then stepped up to the guard post.

"pɝpəs?" æsk ðə junəfɔɹmd ɝæfɛlɪn, hɛɹ ɪn bɹeɪdz.

"Purpose?" asked the uniformed Arafellin, hair in braids.

"tʃɹævlɪŋ tə fæl mɝæn," læn sɛd. "bɪkɔz ə ðə læs bæɾəl."

"Traveling to Fal Moran," Lan said. "Because of the Last Battle."

"jɔɹ nɑt gɑnə weɪt hɪɹ laɪk ðə ɹɛst?" ðə ɡɑɹd sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn ət ðə ɡæðɝd mɔlkɪɹi. "fɔɹ jəɹ kɪŋ?"

"You're not going to wait here like the rest?" the guard said, waving a gauntleted hand at the gathered Malkieri. "For your king?"

"aɪ hæv noʊ kɪŋ," læn sɛd sɔfli.

"I have no king," Lan said softly.

ðə soʊlʒɝ nɑɾəd sloʊli, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. ðən i weɪv fəɹ səm soʊlʒɝz tə ɪnspɛk ðə ɡʊdz ɪn ðə wæɡənz. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi ə tɛɹəf ɑn ðæt."

The soldier nodded slowly, rubbing his chin. Then he waved for some soldiers to inspect the goods in the wagons. "There will be a tariff on that."

"aɪ plæn tə ɡɪv ɪt tə ʃaɪnɝənz tə faɪɾ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl," læn sɛd. "noʊ pɹaɪs æskt."

"I plan to give it to Shienarans to fight in the Last Battle," Lan said. "No price asked."

ðə ɡɑɹd ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

The guard raised an eyebrow.

"ju hæv maɪ oʊθ ɑn ɪt," læn sɛd sɔfli, miɾɪŋ ðə mænz aɪz.

"You have my oath on it," Lan said softly, meeting the man's eyes.

"noʊ tɛɹəf, ðɛn. teɪʃɝ mɔlkiɝ, fɹɛnd."

"No tariff, then. Tai'shar Malkier, friend."

"teɪʃɝ ɝæfəl." læn kɪkt ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd. hi heɪɾəd ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪlvɝwɔlz; ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ðoʊ ə θaʊzən ɑɹtʃɝz wɝ dʒɹɔɪŋ ɑn hɪm. ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd nɑɾ izəli ɡɛt θɹu hɪɹ, ɪf ði ɝæfɛlɪn wɝ fɔɹs tə ɹitʃɹit bæk ðɪs fɑɹ. ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz ðət hæd hæpənd, ən ðeɪ hæd hɛl hɪɹ itʃ taɪm, əz ɪn ðə deɪz ə jækəbɪn ði əndɔntɪd.

"Tai'shar Arafel." Lan kicked his horse forward. He hated riding through the Silverwalls; they made him feel as though a thousand archers were drawing on him. The Trollocs would not easily get through here, if the Arafellin were forced to retreat back this far. There were times that had happened, and they had held here each time, as in the days of Yakobin the Undaunted.

læn pɹæktəkli hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ ði ɪntaɪɝ weɪ. hi ɹitʃt ði ʌðɝ saɪd ɡɹeɪtfəli, ən ɝdʒ mændɑɹb aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹoʊdweɪ tə ðə nɔɹθist.

Lan practically held his breath the entire way. He reached the other side gratefully, and urged Mandarb out onto the roadway to the northeast.

læn fɛlt laɪk boʊltɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪf i dɪd, ðɪs pɝsən wəd ʃʊɹli kɔl bæk tə ði ʌðɝz. hi weɪɾəd.

Lan felt like bolting. But if he did, this person would surely call back to the others. He waited.

ðə fɪɡjɝ keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs dɔɹweɪz. læn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm: ə bɔɪ nɑt jɛt ɡɹoʊn ɪndə ə mæn wɛɹɪŋ ɹɛd, wɪð ə ɹɪtʃ blu kloʊk. kseɪ nɔɹəmɑɡə, ɡɹændsʌn ə ðə kwin ə kændɝ.

Burn that woman, Lan thought as he heard a call being raised through the fortress. He'd been outmaneuvered. Curse Nynaeve. And bless her, too. He tried to send a sense of love and frustration through the bond to her.
