"du jə ɡɪv pɝmɪʃən, ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd? ʃi æskt. "ðɪs wʌn ɪz tu fɑɹ ɡɔn tə spik fəɹ hɪmsɛlf."

"Do you give permission, Galad Damodred? she asked. "This one is too far gone to speak for himself."

ɡɑləd hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ itʃ tʃaɪl bi ɡɪvən ðə tʃɔɪs tə ɹəfjuz hilɪŋ, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðɛɹ waʊnd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz hædn laɪkt ɪt, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd ɹɪpiɾɪd ði ɔɹɾɝ. ðeɪ sim tə lɪsən tə hɪm. ɑd. ɡɑləd hæd ɹɛɹli mɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wəd lɪsən tə ði ɔɹɾɝz, əɹ ivən əpɪnjənz, ʌv ə mæn.

Galad had insisted that each Child be given the choice to refuse Healing, regardless of the nature of their wound. The Aes Sedai and Wise Ones hadn't liked it, but Perrin had repeated the order. They seemed to listen to him. Odd. Galad had rarely met Aes Sedai who would listen to the orders, or even opinions, of a man.

"jɛs," ɡɑləd sɛd. "hil hɪm."

"Yes," Galad said. "Heal him."

ðə waɪz wʌn tɝn tə hɝ wɝk. moʊs tʃɪlʒɹən hæd ɹəfjuz hilɪŋ, ðoʊ səm hæd tʃeɪnʒd ðɛɹ maɪnz wʌns ɡɑləd hɪmsɛlf æksɛptɪɾ ɪt. ðə juθs bɹiðɪŋ stɛɾid, hɪz waʊn kloʊzɪŋ. ðə waɪz wʌn dɪdn hil ɪm kəmplitli - oʊnli fɑɹ ɪnʌf ðət hid sɝvaɪv ðə deɪ. wən ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ʃi lʊk hæɡɝd, ivən mɔɹ taɪɝd ðən ɡɑləd fɛlt.

The Wise One turned to her work. Most Children had refused Healing, though some had changed their minds once Galad himself accepted it. The youth's breathing steadied, his wound closing. The Wise One didn't Heal him completely - only far enough that he'd survive the day. When she opened her eyes, she looked haggard, even more tired than Galad felt.

ðə tʃænlɝz hæd fɔɾ ɔl naɪt, fɑloʊd baɪ pɝfɔɹmɪŋ hilɪŋz. ɡɑləɾ ən pɛɹɪn muv bæk ɑntu ðə fild. ðeɪ wɝn ði oʊnli wʌnz sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ wundəd, ʌv kɔɹs. pɛɹɪn hɪmsɛlf cʊɾə ɡɔn bæk tə kæmp tə ɹɛst. bʌɾ i hædnt.

The channelers had fought all night, followed by performing Healings. Galad and Perrin moved back onto the field. They weren't the only ones searching for wounded, of course. Perrin himself could have gone back to camp to rest. But he hadn't.

"aɪ kən ɔfɝ jə ənʌðɝ ɑpʃən," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ əz ðeɪ wɔkt. "æz əpoʊz tə steɪɪŋ hɪɹ, ɪn ɡildən, wiks fɹəm jəɹ dɛstəneɪʃən. aɪ kəɾ əv jə ɪn ændɝ tənaɪt."

"I can offer you another option," Perrin said as they walked. "As opposed to staying here, in Ghealdan, weeks from your destination. I could have you in Andor tonight."

"maɪ mɛn wəd nɑt tʃɹʌs ðɪs tʃɹævlɪŋ."

"My men would not trust this Traveling."

"ðeɪd ɡoʊ ɪf jə ɔɹɾɝd ðɛm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "juv sɛd ðət jəl faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"They'd go if you ordered them," Perrin said. "You've said that you'll fight alongside Aes Sedai.

wɛl, aɪ doʊn si ɛniθɪŋ dɪfɹən bɪtwin ðəɾ ən ðɪs. kʌm wɪð mi."

Well, I don't see anything different between that and this. Come with me."

"jud lɛɾ əs dʒɔɪn ju, ðɛn?"

"You'd let us join you, then?"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪd niɾ ən oʊθ fɹəm ju, ðoʊ."

Perrin nodded. "I'd need an oath from you, though."

"wʌt mænɝ ʌv oʊθ?"

"What manner of oath?"

"aɪl bi fɹæŋk wɪð ju, ɡɑləd. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wɪv mʌtʃ taɪm lɛft. ə fju wiks, meɪbi. wɛl, aɪ fænsi wɪl nid ju, bʌt ɹænd woʊn laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv waɪtkloʊks ɪn ðə bæɾəl laɪnz ənsupɝvaɪzd. soʊ, aɪ wɑn jə tə swɛɹ jəl æksɛp mi əz jəɹ kəmændɝ əntɪl ðə bæɾəl ɪz θɹu."

"I'll be frank with you, Galad. I don't think we have much time left. A few weeks, maybe. Well, I fancy we'll need you, but Rand won't like the idea of Whitecloaks in the battle lines unsupervised. So, I want you to swear you'll accept me as your commander until the battle is through."

ɡɑləd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. dɔn wɑz kloʊs naʊ; ɪn fækt, ɪt maɪɾ əv ɝaɪvd, bɪhaɪn ðoʊz klaʊdz. "du jə ɹilaɪz wʌɾ ən ɑdeɪʃəs sədʒɛstʃən jə meɪk? ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ oʊbeɪɪŋ ði ɔɹɾɝz ʌv ɛni mæn wəd bi ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl. bʌt tə ju, ə mæn aɪ dʒʌst ɹisənli sɔ dʒʌdʒd ə kɪlɝ? ə mæn moʊst ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ kənvɪnst ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd?"

Galad hesitated. Dawn was close now; in fact, it might have arrived, behind those clouds. "Do you realize what an audacious suggestion you make? The Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light obeying the orders of any man would be remarkable. But to you, a man I just recently saw judged a killer? A man most of the Children are convinced is a Darkfriend?"

pɛɹɪn tɝn tə hɪm. "ju kʌm wɪð mi naʊ, ən əl ɡɛt jə tə ðə læs bæɾəl. wɪθaʊt mi, hu noʊz wʌt wɪl hæpən?"

Perrin turned to him. "You come with me now, and I'll get you to the Last Battle. Without me, who knows what will happen?"

"ju sɛɾ ɛvɹi sɔɹd wɑz niɾəd," ɡɑləd ɹɪplaɪd. "jud liv ʌs?"

"You said every sword was needed," Galad replied. "You'd leave us?"

"jɛs. ɪf aɪ doʊn əv ðəɾ oʊθ, aɪ wɪl. ɹænd meɪ kʌm bæk fəɹ jə hɪmsɛlf, ðoʊ. ɪn mi, jə noʊ wʌt jəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ. əl bi fɛɹ tə ju. ɔl əl æsk ɪz ðət jəɹ mɛn steɪ ɪn laɪn, ðən faɪt wɛɹ ðəɹ toʊld wən ðə bæɾəl kʌmz. ɹænd . . . wɛl, jə kən seɪ noʊ tə mi. jəl faɪn ɪt mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ tə seɪ ɪt tə hɪm. ən aɪ daʊt jəl laɪk ðə ɹɪzʌl hæf əz mʌtʃ, iðɝ, wʌns jə ɛn ʌp seɪɪŋ jɛs."

"Yes. If I don't have that oath, I will. Rand may come back for you himself, though. In me, you know what you're getting. I'll be fair to you. All I'll ask is that your men stay in line, then fight where they're told when the battle comes. Rand . . . well, you can say no to me. You'll find it much harder to say it to him. And I doubt you'll like the result half as much, either, once you end up saying yes."

ɡɑləd fɹaʊnd. "jɔɹ ən ɑdli kəmpɛlɪŋ mæn, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

Galad frowned. "You're an oddly compelling man, Perrin Aybara."

"wi hæv ə bɑɹɡən?" pɛɹɪn hɛld aʊɾ ə hænd.

"We have a bargain?" Perrin held out a hand.

ɡɑləd tʊk ɪt. ɪt wɑzn ðə θɹɛt ðət dɪɾ ɪt; ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ pɛɹɪnz vɔɪs wən hid faʊn dʒɪɹəm wundəd. ðət kəmpæʃən. noʊ dɑɹkfɹɛn kəd feɪn ðæt.

Galad took it. It wasn't the threat that did it; it was remembering Perrin's voice when he'd found Jerum wounded. That compassion. No Darkfriend could feign that.

"ju hæv maɪ oʊθ," ɡɑləd sɛd. "tə æksɛp jə əz maɪ mɪlətɛɹi kəmændɝ əntɪl ði ɛn ə ðə læs bæɾəl," hi sʌɾənli fɛlt wikɝ ðən i hæd bɪfɔɹ, ən i ɹilist ə bɹɛθ, ðən sæɾ ɑn ə nɪɹbaɪ ɹɑk.

"You have my oath," Galad said. "To accept you as my military commander until the end of the Last Battle," He suddenly felt weaker than he had before, and he released a breath, then sat on a nearby rock.

"æn juv maɪ oʊθ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪl si jəɹ mɛn kɛɹd fəɹ laɪk ði ʌðɝz. sɪt hɪɹ ən ɹɛst ə spɛl; əl sɝtʃ ðət pætʃ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ. ðə wiknəs wɪl pæs sun."

"And you have my oath," Perrin said. "I'll see your men cared for like the others. Sit here and rest a spell; I'll search that patch over there. The weakness will pass soon."

"wiknəs?"

"Weakness?"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪts laɪk tə bi kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ðə nidz ʌv ə tɑvɝən. laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ du."

Perrin nodded. "I know what it's like to be caught up in the needs of a ta'veren. Light, but I do."

hi aɪd ɡɑləd. "ju ɛvɝ wʌndɝ waɪ wi ɛndəɾ ʌp hɪɹ, ɪn ðɪs seɪm pleɪs?"

He eyed Galad. "You ever wonder why we ended up here, in this same place?"

"maɪ mɛn ən aɪ əsumd ɪt wɑz kəz ðə laɪt hæd pleɪs jə bɪfɔɹ ʌs," ɡɑləd sɛd. "soʊ wi kəd pʌnɪʃ ju."

"My men and I assumed it was because the Light had placed you before us," Galad said. "So we could punish you."

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðæts nɑɾ ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. tʃɹuθ ɪz, ɡɑləd, aɪ əpɛɹənli niɾəd ju. ən ðæts waɪ jə ɛndəɾ ʌp hɪɹ." wɪð ðæt, hi hɛɾəd ɔf.

Perrin shook his head. "That's not it at all. Truth is, Galad, I apparently needed you. And that's why you ended up here." With that, he headed off.

æliændɝ kɛɹfəli foʊldəd ðə bændɪdʒ, ðən pæst ɪt tə ə weɪɾɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz wɝ θɪk ən kælʌzd, hɪz feɪs hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz ɹoʊb. ʃi θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi naɪəɡən, ðə bɹʌðɝləs ðət lətʃəl hæd bɪn teɪkɪŋ æftɝ. ðət stɪl ɝk feɪl, bʌɾ eɪliændɝ kʊdn fæðəm waɪ. ən il mæn wəd pɹɑbli mætʃ lətʃəl wɛl.

Alliandre carefully folded the bandage, then passed it to a waiting gai'shain. His fingers were thick and callused, his face hidden beneath the hood of his robe. She thought it might be Niagen, the Brotherless that Lacile had been taking after. That still irked Faile, but Ailiandre couldn't fathom why. An Aiel man would probably match Lacile well.

eɪliændɝ bɪɡæn ɹoʊlɪŋ ənʌðɝ bændɪdʒ. ʃi sæt wɪð ʌðɝ wɪmən ɪn ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ nɪɹ ðə bæɾəlfild, sɝaʊndəd baɪ skɹæɡli skæɾɝhɛd ən stænz ə lɛðɝlif. ðə kul ɛɹ wɑz kwaɪət seɪv fəɹ ðə nɪɹbaɪ ɡɹoʊn ə ðə wundəd.

Ailiandre began rolling another bandage. She sat with other women in a small clearing near the battlefield, surrounded by scraggly scatterhead and stands of leatherleaf. The cool air was quiet save for the nearby groan of the wounded.

ʃi kʌɾ ənʌðɝ lɛŋθ ə klɔθ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt. ðə klɔθ hæd bɪn ə ʃɝt. naʊ ɪt wɑz bændədʒəz. nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt lɔs; ɪt hædn bɪn ə vɛɹi ɡʊd ʃɝt, baɪ ðə lʊks ʌv ɪt.

She cut another length of cloth in the morning light. The cloth had been a shirt. Now it was bandages. Not a great loss; it hadn't been a very good shirt, by the looks of it.

"ðə bæɾəl ɪz θɹu?" bɹəleɪn sɛd sɔfli. ʃi ən feɪl wɝk nɪɹbaɪ, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn stulz əkɹɔs fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ðeɪ kʌt.

"The battle is through?" Berelain said softly. She and Faile worked nearby, sitting on stools across from one another as they cut.

"jɛs, ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðəɾ ɪɾ ɪz," feɪl ɹɪplaɪd.

"Yes, it appears that it is," Faile replied.

boʊθ fɛl saɪlənt. eɪliændɝ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt dɪd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn bɪtwin ðoʊz tu. waɪ sʌɾənli stɑɹt pɹitɛndɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ə fɹɛnz? ði æk sim tə ful mɛni ʌv ðə mɛn ɪn kæmp, bʌɾ eɪliændɝ kəd si ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn ðə weɪ ðɛɹ lɪps taɪɾənd wən ðeɪ sɔ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪt hæd lɛsən æftɝ feɪl hæd seɪv bɪɹ-leɪnz laɪf, bʌt nɑt vænɪʃt ɪntaɪɝli.

Both fell silent. Ailiandre raised an eyebrow, but did not say anything. Something was going on between those two. Why suddenly start pretending they were the greatest of friends? The act seemed to fool many of the men in camp, but Ailiandre could see the truth in the way their lips tightened when they saw one another. It had lessened after Faile had saved Bere-lain's life, but not vanished entirely.

"ju wɝ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt hɪm," bɹəleɪn sɛd.

"You were right about him," Berelain said.

"ju saʊn sɝpɹaɪzd."

"You sound surprised."

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ɔfən ɹɔŋ wən ɪt kʌmz tə mɛn."

"I am not often wrong when it comes to men."

"maɪ hʌzbən ɪz nɑt laɪk ʌðɝ mɛn. ɪt - " feɪl kʌɾ ɔf. ʃi lʊk təwɔɹɾ eɪliændɝ, aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ.

"My husband is not like other men. It - " Faile cut off. She looked toward Ailiandre, eyes narrowing.

blʌɾi æʃəz, eɪliændɝ θɔt. ʃid sæt tu fɑɹ əweɪ, wɪtʃ meɪɾ əɹ stʃɹeɪn, tɝnɪŋ tə ivzdʒɹɑp. ðət wɑz səspɪʃəs.

Bloody ashes, Ailiandre thought. She'd sat too far away, which made her strain, turning to eavesdrop. That was suspicious.

ðə tu ʌv əm fɛl saɪlən əɡɛn, ən eɪliændɝ hɛld ʌp ə hænd, əz ɪf ɪnspɛktɪŋ əɹ neɪlz. jɛs, ʃi θɔt. ɪɡnɔɹ mi. aɪ doʊn mæɾɝ, aɪm dʒʌst ə wʊmən ɪn oʊvɝ əɹ hɛɾ ən stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kip ʌp. feɪl ən bɹəleɪn dɪdn θɪŋk ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn hæɾ ɛvɝ θɔt pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn ənfeɪθfəl. ɪf jə sæɾ əm daʊn ən æskt əm - ɹɪli meɪɾ əm θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt - ðeɪd kʌm tə ðə kənkluʒən ðət sʌmθɪŋ ɛls mʌst əv hæpənd.

The two of them fell silent again, and Ailiandre held up a hand, as if inspecting her nails. Yes, she thought. Ignore me. I don't matter, I'm just a woman in over her head and struggling to keep up. Faile and Berelain didn't think that, of course, any more than the Two Rivers men had ever thought Perrin had been unfaithful. If you sat them down and asked them - really made them think about it - they'd come to the conclusion that something else must have happened.

bʌt θɪŋz laɪk supɝstɪʃən ən baɪəs ɹæn dipɝ ðən mɪɹ θɔts. wʌt ði ʌðɝ tu θɔɾ əbaʊɾ eɪliændɝ ən wʌt ðeɪ ɪnstɪŋktɪvli fɛlt wɝ dɪfɹənt. bɪsaɪdz, eɪliændɝ ɹɪli wɑz ə wʊmən u wɑz ɪn oʊvɝ əɹ hɛɾ ən stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kip ʌp.

But things like superstition and bias ran deeper than mere thoughts. What the other two thought about Ailiandre and what they instinctively felt were different. Besides, Ailiandre really was a woman who was in over her head and struggling to keep up.

bɛs tə noʊ wʌt jəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθs wɝ.

Best to know what your strengths were.

eɪliændɝ tɝn bæk tə kʌɾɪŋ bændədʒəz. feɪl ən bɹəleɪn hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn steɪɪŋ tə hɛlp;

Ailiandre turned back to cutting bandages. Faile and Berelain had insisted on staying to help;

eɪliændɝ kʊdnt ɡoʊ. nɑt wɪð ðə tu ʌv əm æktɪŋ soʊ blʌɾi fæsəneɪɾɪŋ leɪtli. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi dɪdn maɪn ðə wɝk. kɑm- pɛɹd tə ðɛɹ kæptɪvəɾi baɪ ði il, ðɪs wɑz ɹɪli kwaɪt plɛzənt. ənfɝ-tʌnsli, ðə tu dɪdnt ɡoʊ bæk tə ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ɪn fækt, bɹəleɪn ɹoʊz, lʊkɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd, ən wɔk təwɔɹd ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ.

Ailiandre couldn't go. Not with the two of them acting so bloody fascinating lately. Besides, she didn't mind the work. Com- pared to their captivity by the Aiel, this was really quite pleasant. Unfor-tunstely, the two didn't go back to their conversation. In fact, Berelain rose, looking frustrated, and walked toward the other side of the clearing.

æliændɝ kəd pɹæktəkli fil ðə fɹɔs kʌmɪŋ ɔf ðə wʊmən. bɹəleɪn stɑpt oʊvɝ wɛɹ ʌðɝz wɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə stʃɹɪps ə klɔθ. æliændɝ stʊɾ ʌp, kæɹiɪŋ əɹ stul, sɪzɝz ən klɔθs oʊvɝ tə feɪl. "aɪ doʊn bɪliv aɪv ɛvɝ sin əɹ ðɪs ənsɛɾəld," æliændɝ sɛd.

Alliandre could practically feel the frost coming off the woman. Berelain stopped over where others were rolling the strips of cloth. Alliandre stood up, carrying her stool, scissors and cloths over to Faile. "I don't believe I've ever seen her this unsettled," Alliandre said.

"ʃiz nɑt fɑn ə biɪŋ ɹɔŋ," feɪl noʊɾəd. ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ʃi siz ðə wɝld əz ə nɛtwɝk ə hæf-tʃɹuθs ən ɪnfɝɛnsɪz, əskɹaɪbɪŋ kɑmplɛks moʊɾəveɪʃənz tə ðə sɪmpləst ə mɛn. aɪ səspɛkt ɪt meɪks əɹ vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət kɔɹt pɑlətɪks. bʌɾ aɪ wʊdnt wɑnə lɪv ðət weɪ."

"She's not fond of being wrong," Faile noted. She took a deep breath, then shook her head. "She sees the world as a network of half-truths and inferences, ascribing complex motivations to the simplest of men. I suspect it makes her very good at court politics. But I wouldn't want to live that way."

"ʃiz vɛɹi waɪz," æliændɝ sɛd. "ʃi dʌz si θɪŋz, feɪl. ʃi ʌndɝstænz ðə wɝld, ʃi mɪɹli hæz ə fju blaɪn spɑts, laɪk moʊst ʌv ʌs."

"She's very wise," Alliandre said. "She does see things, Faile. She understands the world, she merely has a few blind spots, like most of us."

feɪl nɑɾəd æbsənli. "ðə θɪŋ aɪ pɪɾi moʊst ɪz ðə fæk ðæt, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ə ðɪs, aɪ doʊn bɪliv ʃi wɑz ɛvɝ ɪn lʌv wɪð pɛɹɪn. ʃi tʃeɪst ɪm fəɹ spɔɹt, fəɹ pəlɪɾəkəl ædvæntɪdʒ, ən fəɹ min. ɪn ði ɛnd, ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðə tʃælənʒ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ʃi meɪ bi fɑn ə hɪm, bʌt nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ. aɪ kʊd, pɝhæps, ʌndɝstæn əɹ ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn fəɹ lʌv."

Faile nodded absently. "The thing I pity most is the fact that, despite all of this, I don't believe she was ever in love with Perrin. She chased him for sport, for political advantage, and for Mayene. In the end, it was more the challenge than anything else. She may be fond of him, but nothing more. I could, perhaps, understand her if it had been for love."

æliændɝ kɛpt əɹ tʌŋ æftɝ ðæt, kʌɾɪŋ bændədʒəz. ʃi ɹæn əkɹɔs ə faɪn blu sɪlk ʃɝɾ ɪn ðə paɪl. ʃʊɹli ðəɹ kəd bi sʌmθɪŋ bɛɾɝ dʌn wɪð ðæt! ʃi stʌft ɪt bɪtwin tu ʌðɝz ən sɛt ðoʊz bɪsaɪd hɝ, əz ɪf ɪn ə paɪl ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə kʌt.

Alliandre kept her tongue after that, cutting bandages. She ran across a fine blue silk shirt in the pile. Surely there could be something better done with that! She stuffed it between two others and set those beside her, as if in a pile she intended to cut.

pɛɹɪn ɪvɛntʃəwəli tʃɹæmpt ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ, fɑloʊd baɪ səm wɝkɝz ɪn blʌɾid kloʊðɪŋ. hi meɪɾ ɪnstənli fəɹ feɪl, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn bɪɹ-leɪnz stul, sɛɾɪŋ ɪz mɑɹvələs hæmɝ daʊn ɪn ðə widz bɪsaɪd hɪm. hi lʊkt ɪɡzɔstəd. feɪl ɡɑɾ ɪm sʌmθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk ən ðən ɹʌbd ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

Perrin eventually tramped into the clearing, followed by some workers in bloodied clothing. He made instantly for Faile, sitting down on Bere-lain's stool, setting his marvelous hammer down in the weeds beside him. He looked exhausted. Faile got him something to drink and then rubbed his shoulder.

æliændɝ ɪkskjuz hɝsɛlf, livɪŋ pɛɹɪn ən ɪz waɪf. ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ oʊvɝ tə wɛɹ bɹəleɪn stʊɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ, sɪpɪŋ ə kʌp ə ti teɪkən fɹəm ðə pɑɾ ɑn ðə faɪɝ. bɹəleɪn aɪd hɝ.

Alliandre excused herself, leaving Perrin and his wife. She made her way over to where Berelain stood at the edge of the clearing, sipping a cup of tea taken from the pot on the fire. Berelain eyed her.

æliændɝ pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti, ðən blu ɑn ɪt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡʊd fəɹ wʌn ənʌðɝ, bɹəleɪn," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ kænɑt seɪ aɪm sɑɹi tə si ðɪs ɹɪzʌlt."

Alliandre poured herself a cup of tea, then blew on it for a moment. They are good for one another, Berelain," she said. "I cannot say I'm sorry to see this result."

"ɛvɹi ɹileɪʃənʃɪp dɪzɝvz tə bi tʃælənʒd," bɹəleɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "æn ɪf ʃi hæd fɔlən ɪn meɪɾən - ən aʊtkʌm ɔl tu pɑsəbəl - hi wʊɾə niɾəd sʌmwʌn. ɪts nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt lɔs tə mi, haʊɛvɝ, tə teɪk maɪ aɪz ɔf pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. aɪ wʊɾə laɪk tə meɪk ə kənɛkʃən tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn θɹu hɪm, bʌt ðəɹ wɪl bi ʌðɝ ɑpɝtunəɾiz." ʃi sim fɑɹ lɛs fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd naʊ ðən ʃi hæd moʊməns əɡoʊ. ɪn fækt, ʃi sim tə hæv ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ sɛlf.

"Every relationship deserves to be challenged," Berelain replied. "And if she had fallen in Maiden - an outcome all too possible - he would have needed someone. It is not a great loss to me, however, to take my eyes off Perrin Aybara. I would have liked to make a connection to the Dragon Reborn through him, but there will be other opportunities." She seemed far less frustrated now than she had moments ago. In fact, she seemed to have returned to her calculating self.

æliændɝ smaɪld. klɛvɝ wʊmən. feɪl niɾəd tə si hɝ ɹaɪvəl kɑm-plɛtli biɾən daʊn, soʊ ðət ʃi wəd kənsɪɾɝ ɹə θɹɛt pæst. ðɪs wɑz waɪ bɹəleɪn lɛt səm ə hɝ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ʃoʊ, mɔɹ ðən ʃi nɔɹməli wəd hæv.

Alliandre smiled. Clever woman. Faile needed to see her rival com-pletely beaten down, so that she would consider rhe threat passed. This was why Berelain let some of her frustration show, more than she normally would have.

æliændɝ sɪpt əɹ ti. "mɛɹɪdʒ simz nʌθɪŋ tə jə ʌðɝ ðən ə kælkjəleɪʃən, ðɛn? ði ædvæntɪdʒɪz ɡeɪnd?"

Alliandre sipped her tea. "Marriage seems nothing to you other than a calculation, then? The advantages gained?"

"ðɛɹz ɔlsoʊ ðə dʒɔɪ ʌv ðə hʌnt, ðə θɹɪl ə ðə ɡeɪm."

"There's also the joy of the hunt, the thrill of the game."

"ænd wʌɾ ə lʌv?"

"And what of love?"

"lʌv ɪz fəɹ ðoʊz u də nɑt ɹul," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "ə wʊmən ɪz wɝθ fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən əɹ əbɪləɾi tə meɪk ə mætʃ, bʌɾ aɪ mʌs kɛɹ fəɹ min. ɪf wi ɛntɝ ðə læs bæɾəl wɪθaʊt maɪ hævɪŋ sɪkjʊɹɾ ə hʌzbənd, ðət pʊts ðə səksɛʃən ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ən wən min əz ə səksɛʃən kɹaɪsəs, tiɹ ɪz ɔl tu kwɪk tə əsɝɾ ɪtsɛlf. ɹoʊmæns ɪz ən ənəfɔɹɾəbəl dɪstʃɹækʃən aɪ. . ."

"Love is for those who do not rule," Berelain said. "A woman is worth far more than her ability to make a match, but I must care for Mayene. If we enter the Last Battle without my having secured a husband, that puts the succession in danger. And when Mayene has a succession crisis, Tear is all too quick to assert itself. Romance is an unaffordable distraction I. . ."

ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf sʌɾənli, hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn? æliændɝ tɝn tə ðə saɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əntɪl ʃi sɔ ðə kɑz.

She trailed off suddenly, her expression changing. What was going on? Alliandre turned to the side, frowning until she saw the cause.

ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə klɪɹɪŋ.

Galad Damodred had entered the clearing.

hi hæd blʌɾ ɑn ɪz waɪt junəfɔɹm, ən i lʊkt ɪɡzɔstəd. jɛɾ i stʊɾ əpɹaɪt, stʃɹeɪt- bækt, ən ɪz feɪs wɑz klin. hi ɔlmoʊst sim tu bjuɾəfəl tə bi hjumən, wɪð ðət pɝfəkli mæskjələn feɪs ən ɡɹeɪsfəl, lin fɪɡjɝ. ən ðoʊz aɪz! laɪk dip, dɑɹk pulz. hi pɹæktəkli sim tə ɡloʊ.

He had blood on his white uniform, and he looked exhausted. Yet he stood upright, straight- backed, and his face was clean. He almost seemed too beautiful to be human, with that perfectly masculine face and graceful, lean figure. And those eyes! Like deep, dark pools. He practically seemed to glow.

"aɪ. . . wʌt wɑz aɪ seɪɪŋ?" bɹəleɪn æskt, aɪz ɑn dəmədʒɹd.

"I. . . What was I saying?" Berelain asked, eyes on Damodred.

"ðæt ðəɹ ɪz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ɹoʊmæns ɪn ə liɾɝz laɪf?"

"That there is no place for romance in a leaders life?"

"jɛs," bɹəleɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ dɪstʃɹæktəd. "ɪts dʒʌs nɑt ɹizənəbəl əɾ ɔl."

"Yes," Berelain said, sounding distracted. "It's just not reasonable at all."

"nɑɾ əɾ ɔl."

"Not at all."

"aɪ - " bɹəleɪn bɪɡæn, bʌt dəmədʒɹd tɝn təwɔɹd ðɛm. ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz ðɛɹ aɪz mɛt.

"I - " Berelain began, but Damodred turned toward them. She cut off as their eyes met.

æliændɝ səpɹɛst ə smaɪl əz dəmədʒɹd kɹɔs ðə klɪɹɪŋ. hi ɛksəkjuɾəd ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ə pɝfək baʊz, wʌn fəɹ itʃ ə ðɛm, ðoʊ hi bɛɹli sim tə noʊɾəs æliændɝ.

Alliandre suppressed a smile as Damodred crossed the clearing. He executed another set of perfect bows, one for each of them, though he barely seemed to notice Alliandre.

"maɪ . . . leɪɾi fɝst," hi sɛd. "lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə sɛz ðæt, wən i fɝst əpɹoʊtʃt ðɪs bæɾəl, jə plɛd tə hɪm ɑn maɪ bɪhæf."

"My . . . Lady First," he said. "Lord Aybara says that, when he first approached this battle, you pled to him on my behalf."

"fulɪʃli," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "aɪ fɪɹɾ i wəɾ ətæk ju."

"Foolishly," Berelain said. "I feared he would attack you."

"ɪf fɪɹɪŋ ðət meɪks wʌn ə ful," dəmədʒɹd sɛd, "ðɛn wi tu ɑɹ fulz təɡɛðɝ ɪn ɪt. aɪ wɑz sɝɾən ðət maɪ mɛn wəd sun fɔl tə eɪbɑɹə.

"If fearing that makes one a fool," Damodred said, "then we two are fools together in it. I was certain that my men would soon fall to Aybara.

ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm. ðət kwɪkli, ʃi sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃid bɪn seɪɪŋ pɹiviəsli.

She smiled at him. That quickly, she seemed to have forgotten everything she'd been saying previously.

"wʊd jə laɪk səm ti?" dəmədʒɹd sɛd, spikɪŋ ə lɪɾəl əbɹʌpli əz i ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə tikəps, wɪtʃ sæɾ ɑn ə klɔθ əweɪ fɹəm ðə faɪɝ.

"Would you like some tea?" Damodred said, speaking a little abruptly as he reached for the teacups, which sat on a cloth away from the fire.

"aɪm dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ sʌm," ʃi noʊɾəd.

"I'm drinking some," she noted.

"sʌm mɔɹ ðɛn?" hi æskt, heɪstəli nilɪŋ ən pɔɹɪŋ ə kʌp.

"Some more then?" he asked, hastily kneeling and pouring a cup.

"ɝ."

"Er."

hi stʊɾ ʌp, hoʊldɪŋ ðə kʌp, ðən siɪŋ ðət ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hæd wʌn ɪn əɹ hænz.

He stood up, holding the cup, then seeing that she already had one in her hands.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ stɪl bændədʒəz tə kʌt," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "pɝhæps jə kəd hɛlp."

"There are still bandages to cut," Berelain said. "Perhaps you could help."

"pɝhæps," hi sɛd. hi hændəd ðə kʌp hid pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ tə æliændɝ. bɹəleɪn - hɝ aɪz stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ɪz - hændəd hɝz oʊvɝ əz wɛl, simɪŋ əblɪviəs tə wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ.

"Perhaps," he said. He handed the cup he'd poured over to Alliandre. Berelain - her eyes still holding his - handed hers over as well, seeming oblivious to what she was doing.

æliændɝ smaɪl dipli - naʊ hoʊldɪŋ θɹi tikəps - əz ðə tu ʌv əm wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ðə stæk ə klɔθs tə bi kʌt. ðɪs maɪt tɝn aʊt wɛl ɪndid. ət ðə vɛɹi list, ɪt wəd ɡɛt ðoʊz blæstəd waɪtkloʊks aʊɾ ə hɝ kɪŋdəm.

Alliandre smiled deeply - now holding three teacups - as the two of them walked over to the stack of cloths to be cut. This might turn out well indeed. At the very least, it would get those blasted Whitecloaks out of her kingdom.

ʃi wɔk bæk təwɔɹd feɪl ən pɛɹɪn. əz ʃi dɪd soʊ, ʃi slɪp ðə blu sɪlk ʃɝt fɹəm ðə paɪl ə klɔθ ʃid sɛɾ əsaɪd tə kʌt.

She walked back toward Faile and Perrin. As she did so, she slipped the blue silk shirt from the pile of cloth she'd set aside to cut.

ɪt ɹɪli wəd meɪk ə naɪs sæʃ.

It really would make a nice sash.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 44

eɪ bækhændəd ɹɪkwɛst


A Backhanded Request

mɔɹɡeɪs stɛpt aʊɾ ə hɝ hɪlsaɪd tɛn ən lʊkt aʊɾ əɾ ændɝ. waɪtbɹɪdʒ leɪ bɪloʊ, blɛsədli fəmɪljɝ, ɔlðoʊ ʃi kəd si ðəɾ ɪt hæd ɡɹoʊn. ðə fɑɹmz wɝ feɪlɪŋ, ðə læst ə ðə wɪntɝ stɔɹz spɔɪlɪŋ, soʊ pipəl meɪd fəɹ ðə sɪɾiz.

Morgase stepped out of her hillside tent and looked out at Andor. Whitebridge lay below, blessedly familiar, although she could see that it had grown. The farms were failing, the last of the winter stores spoiling, so people made for the cities.

ðə lændskeɪp ʃʊɾə bɪn ɡɹin. ɪnstɛd, ivən ðə jɛloʊd ɡɹæs wɑz daɪɪŋ ɔf, livɪŋ skɑɹz ə bɹaʊn. ɪt wʊdn bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ lænd wɑz laɪk ðə weɪst. ʃi lɔŋ tə teɪk ækʃən. ðɪs wɑz əɹ neɪʃən. əɹ ɪt hæd wʌns bɪn.

The landscape should have been green. Instead, even the yellowed grass was dying off, leaving scars of brown. It wouldn't be long before the entire land was like the Waste. She longed to take action. This was her nation. Or it had once been.

ʃi lɛft əɹ tɛnt, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mæstɝ ɡɪl. ɑn ðə weɪ, ʃi pæs feɪl, hu wɑz spikɪŋ wɪð ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ əɡɛn. mɔɹɡeɪs nɑɾəd, ʃoʊɪŋ dɛfɝəns. feɪl nɑɾəd bæk. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɪf bɪtwin ðə tu ʌv əm naʊ. mɔɹɡeɪs wɪʃt ɪt kəd bi ʌðɝwaɪz. ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz hæd ʃɛɹɾ ə slɪvɝ ə ðɛɹ laɪvz wən hoʊp hæd bɪn wikɝ ðən ə kændəlz fleɪm. ɪt hæd bɪn feɪl u hæɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒ mɔɹɡeɪs tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ -  skwizɪŋ ɛvɹi læs dʒɹɑp fɹəm əɹ pəθɛɾɪk əbɪləɾi - tə sɪɡnəl fəɹ hɛlp waɪl ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹæpt.

She left her tent, looking for Master Gill. On the way, she passed Faile, who was speaking with the quartermaster again. Morgase nodded, showing deference. Faile nodded back. There was a rift between the two of them now. Morgase wished it could be otherwise. She and the others had shared a sliver of their lives when hope had been weaker than a candle's flame. It had been Faile who had encouraged Morgase to use the One Power -  squeezing every last drop from her pathetic ability - to signal for help while they were trapped.

ðə kæmp wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi wɛl sɛɾ ʌp, ən əmeɪzɪŋli ðə waɪtkloʊks hæd dʒɔɪn ðɛm, bʌt pɛɹɪn hædn jɛt dɪsaɪɾɪd wʌt tə du. əɹ ət list ɪf i hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd, hi wɑznt ʃɛɹɪŋ ðət dɪsɪʒən wɪð mɔɹɡeɪs.

The camp was already well set up, and amazingly the Whitecloaks had joined them, but Perrin hadn't yet decided what to do. Or at least if he had decided, he wasn't sharing that decision with Morgase.

ʃi wɔk tə ðə wæɡən laɪnz, pæs fɛɹiɝz ən ɡɹumz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðə bɛs pæstʃɝ, pipəl ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ɪn ðə səplaɪ dʌmp, soʊlʒɝz ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli dɪɡɪŋ tʃɹɛntʃɪz fəɹ weɪst. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd ðɛɹ pleɪs ɪksɛp mɔɹɡeɪs. sɝvəns bækt əweɪ, hæf-boʊɪŋ, ənsɝɾən haʊ tə tʃɹit hɝ. ʃi wɑzn ə kwin, bʌt niðɝ wɑz ʃi sɪmpli ənʌðɝ noʊbəlwʊmən. ʃi sɝɾənli wɑzn ə sɝvən ɛnimɔɹ.

She walked to the wagon lines, past farriers and grooms looking for the best pasture, people arguing in the supply dump, soldiers grudgingly digging trenches for waste. Everyone had their place except Morgase. Servants backed away, half-bowing, uncertain how to treat her. She wasn't a queen, but neither was she simply another noblewoman. She certainly wasn't a servant anymore.

ðoʊ hɝ taɪm wɪð ɡɑləd hæd ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə bi ə kwin, ʃi wɑz θæŋkfəl fəɹ wʌt ʃi hæd lɝn əz meɪaɪɡdɪn. ðət hædn bɪn əz bæɾ əz ʃi hæd fɪɹd; ðəɹ hæd bɪn ædvæntɪdʒɪz tə biɪŋ ə leɪɾiz meɪd. ðə kɑmɝɑɾɝi ʌv ði ʌðɝ sɝvəns, ðə fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə bɝɾənz ə liɾɝʃɪp, ðə taɪm spɛnt wɪð tɑlænvɝ. . . . ðət laɪf wɑz nɑt hɝz. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bi dʌn wɪð pɹitɛndɪŋ. ʃi ɪvɛntʃəwəli faʊn bɑzəl ɡɪl pækɪŋ ðə kɑɹt, lini supɝvaɪzɪŋ, læmɡwɪn ən bɹin hɛlpɪŋ. feɪl hæd ɹilis bɹin ən læmɡwɪn fɹəm əɹ sɝvəs soʊ ðeɪ kəd sɝv mɔɹɡeɪs. mɔɹɡeɪs hæd kɛp saɪlən əbaʊt feɪl soʊ ɡɹeɪʃəsli ɡɹæntɪŋ əɹ bæk əɹ sɝvəns.

Though her time with Galad had reminded her what it was to be a queen, she was thankful for what she had learned as Maighdin. That hadn't been as bad as she had feared; there had been advantages to being a lady's maid. The camaraderie of the other servants, the freedom from the burdens of leadership, the time spent with Tallanvor. . . . That life was not hers. It was time to be done with pretending. She eventually found Basel Gill packing the cart, Lini supervising, Lamgwin and Breane helping. Faile had released Breane and Lamgwin from her service so they could serve Morgase. Morgase had kept silent about Faile so graciously granting her back her servants.

tɑlænvɝ wɑzn ðɛɹ. wɛl, ʃi kʊdn mun oʊvɝ ɪm laɪk ə ɡɝl ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi hæd tə ɡɛt bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn ən hɛlp ɪleɪn.

Tallanvor wasn't there. Well, she couldn't moon over him like a girl any longer. She had to get back to Caemlyn and help Elayne.

"jɔɹ mədʒz - " mæstɝ ɡɪl sɛd, boʊɪŋ. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ min, maɪ leɪɾi. pɑɹɾən mi."

"Your Majes - " Master Gill said, bowing. He hesitated. "I mean, my Lady. Pardon me."

"doʊn maɪn ɪt, mæstɝ ɡɪl. aɪ hæv tʃɹʌbəl ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ maɪsɛlf."

"Don't mind it, Master Gill. I have trouble remembering myself."

"ju ʃʊɹ jə wɑnə ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðɪs?" lini foʊldəɾ əɹ θɪn ɑɹmz.

"You sure you want to go forward with this?" Lini folded her thin arms.

"jɛs," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz əɹ duɾi tə ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn ən ɔfɝ ɪleɪn wʌɾ əsɪstəns wi kæn."

"Yes," Morgase said. "It is our duty to return to Caemlyn and offer Elayne what assistance we can."

"ɪf jə seɪ soʊ," lini sɛd. "mi, aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u əlaʊz tu ɹustɝz ɪn ðə seɪm bɑɹnjɑɹd dɪzɝvz ðə ɹʌkəs ðeɪ ɡɛt."

"If you say so," Lini said. "Me, I think that anyone who allows two roosters in the same barnyard deserves the ruckus they get."

mɔɹɡeɪs ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "noʊɾəd. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk jəl faɪn ðəɾ aɪm kwaɪt keɪpəbəl ə hɛlpɪŋ wɪθaʊt jusɝpɪŋ əθɔɹəɾi fɹəm ɪleɪn."

Morgase raised an eyebrow. "Noted. But I think you'll find that I am quite capable of helping without usurping authority from Elayne."

lini ʃɹʌɡd.

Lini shrugged.

ʃi hæɾ ə pɔɪnt; mɔɹɡeɪs hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl. steɪɪŋ ɪn ðə kæpəɾəl fəɹ tu lɔŋ kəd θɹoʊ ə ʃædoʊ əkɹɔs ɪleɪn. bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz wʌn θɪŋ mɔɹɡeɪs hæd lɝn fɹəm əɹ mʌnθs əz meɪaɪɡdɪn ɪt wɑz ðət pipəl niɾəd tə bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ pɹədʌktɪv, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əz sɪmpəl əz lɝnɪŋ tə sɝv ti. mɔɹɡeɪs hæd skɪlz ðəɾ ɪleɪn kəd juz fəɹ ðə deɪnʒɝəs taɪmz əhɛd. ɪf ʃi bɪɡæn tə oʊvɝʃæɾoʊ hɝ dɔɾɝ, haʊɛvɝ, ʃi wəd muv aʊɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn tə hɝ hoʊldɪŋz ɪn ðə wɛst.

She had a point; Morgase had to be careful. Staying in the capital for too long could throw a shadow across Elayne. But if there was one thing Morgase had learned from her months as Maighdin it was that people needed to be doing something productive, even if it was something as simple as learning to serve tea. Morgase had skills that Elayne could use for the dangerous times ahead. If she began to overshadow her daughter, however, she would move out of Caemlyn to her holdings in the west.

ði ʌðɝz wɝkt kwɪkli loʊɾɪŋ ʌp, ən mɔɹɡeɪs hæd tə foʊld əɹ ɑɹmz tə kip fɹəm hɛlpɪŋ.

The others worked quickly loading up, and Morgase had to fold her arms to keep from helping.

ðəɹ wɑz ə sɝɾən fʊlfɪlmən tə kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ wʌnsɛlf. əz ʃi weɪɾəd, ʃi noʊɾəst sʌmwʌn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ðə pæθ fɹəm waɪtbɹɪdʒ. tɑlænvɝ. wʌt hæɾ i bɪn duɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi? hi sɔ hɝ ən əpɹoʊtʃt, ðən baʊd, hɪz lin, skwɛɹ feɪs ə mɑɾəl ə dɛfɝəns. "maɪ leɪɾi."

There was a certain fulfillment to caring for oneself. As she waited, she noticed someone riding up the path from Whitebridge. Tallanvor. What had he been doing in the city? He saw her and approached, then bowed, his lean, square face a model of deference. "My Lady."

"ju vɪzəɾəd ðə sɪɾi? dɪd jə ɡɛt lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹəz pɝmɪʃən?" pɛɹɪn hædnt wɑntəɾ ə sʌɾən flʌɾ ə soʊlʒɝz ən ɹɛfjudʒiz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, kɑzɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl.

"You visited the city? Did you get Lord Aybara's permission?" Perrin hadn't wanted a sudden flood of soldiers and refugees going into the city, causing trouble.

"maɪ leɪɾi, aɪ hæv fæmli ðɛɹ," tɑlænvɝ sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ fɹəm ðə sæɾəl. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɪf ən fɔɹməl. "aɪ fɛlt ɪt waɪz tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt ði ɪn-fɔɹmeɪʃən dɪskʌvɝd baɪ lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹəz skaʊts."

"My Lady, I have family there," Tallanvor said, climbing from the saddle. His voice was stiff and formal. "I felt it wise to investigate the in-formation discovered by Lord Aybara's scouts."

"ɪz ðət soʊ, ɡɑɹdzmæn-lutɛnən tɑlænvɝ?" mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. ɪf i kəɾ ækt ɪn sətʃ ə fɔɹməl weɪ, ðən soʊ kəd ʃi. lini, pæsɪŋ wɪð ən ɑɹmloʊɾ ə lɪnənz tə pæk, ɡeɪv ə kwaɪət snɔɹɾ ət mɔɹɡeɪs ɛs toʊn.

"Is that so, Guardsman-Lieutenant Tallanvor?" Morgase said. If he could act in such a formal way, then so could she. Lini, passing with an armload of linens to pack, gave a quiet snort at Morgase s tone.

"jɛs, maɪ leɪɾi," tɑlænvɝ ɹɪplaɪd. "maɪ leɪɾi ... ɪf aɪ meɪ meɪk ə sədʒɛstʃən?"

"Yes, my Lady," Tallanvor replied. "My Lady ... if I may make a suggestion?"

"spik."

"Speak."

"baɪ ɹɪpɔɹts, jəɹ dɔɾɝ stɪl əsumz jə dɛd. aɪm sɝɾən ɪf wi spik tə lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə, hɪl kəmæn ɪz æʃəmən tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ əs tə ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn."

"By reports, your daughter still assumes you dead. I'm certain if we speak to Lord Aybara, he will command his Asha'man to make a gateway for us to return to Caemlyn."

"æn ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ sədʒɛstʃən," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd kɛɹfəli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə smɝk ɑn liniz feɪs əz ʃi wɔk bæk baɪ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən.

"An interesting suggestion," Morgase said carefully, ignoring the smirk on Lini's face as she walked back by in the other direction.

"maɪ leɪɾi," tɑlænvɝ sɛd, aɪɪŋ lini, "maɪt wi spik ɪn pɹaɪvət?"

"My Lady," Tallanvor said, eyeing Lini, "might we speak in private?"

mɔɹɡeɪs nɑɾəd, stɛpɪŋ ɔf tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp. tɑlænvɝ fɑloʊd. ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, ʃi tɝn tə lʊk ət hɪm. "wɛl?"

Morgase nodded, stepping off to the side of the camp. Tallanvor followed. A short distance away, she turned to look at him. "Well?"

"maɪ leɪɾi," hi kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ə sɑftɝ vɔɪs. "ði ændɔɝən kɔɹɾ ɪz sɝɾən tə hɪɹ ðət jə stɪl lɪv, naʊ ðəɾ eɪbɑɹəz ɪntaɪɝ kæmp noʊz. ɪf jə doʊn pɹɛzən jɝsɛlf ən ɪkspleɪn ðət juv ɹɪnaʊns ðə θɹoʊn, ðə ɹumɝz ə jəɹ sɝvaɪvəl kəɾ ɪɹoʊɾ ɪleɪnz əθɔɹəɾi."

"My Lady," he continued in a softer voice. "The Andoran court is certain to hear that you still live, now that Aybara's entire camp knows. If you don't present yourself and explain that you've renounced the throne, the rumors of your survival could erode Elayne's authority."

mɔɹɡeɪs dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ.

Morgase didn't reply.

"ɪf ðə læs bæɾəl tʃɹuli ɪz kʌmɪŋ," tɑlænvɝ sɛd, "wi kæn əfɔɹd - "

"If the Last Battle truly is coming," Tallanvor said, "we can't afford - "

"oʊ, hʌʃ," ʃi sɛd kɝtli. "aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən lini ən ði ʌðɝz ði ɔɹɾɝ tə pæk ʌp. dɪdn jə noʊɾəs wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ?"

"Oh, hush," she said curtly. "I've already given Lini and the others the order to pack up. Didn't you notice what they were doing?"

tɑlænvɝ flʌʃt əz i noʊɾəst ɡɪl hɔlɪŋ ə tʃɛst oʊvɝ ən sɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹt.

Tallanvor flushed as he noticed Gill hauling a chest over and setting it on the cart.

"aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ maɪ fɔɹwɝdnəs. wɪð jəɹ liv, maɪ leɪɾi." tɑlænvɝ nɑɾəd tə hɝ ən tɝn tə ɡoʊ.

"I apologize for my forwardness. With your leave, my Lady." Tallanvor nodded to her and turned to go.

"mʌst wi bi soʊ fɔɹməl wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ, tɑlænvɝ?"

"Must we be so formal with one another, Tallanvor?"

"ði ɪluʒən əz ɛndəd, maɪ leɪɾi." hi wɔkt əweɪ.

"The illusion has ended, my Lady." He walked away.

mɔɹɡeɪs wɑtʃt ɪm ɡoʊ, ən fɛlt əɹ hɑɹt twɪst. kɝs əɹ stʌbɝnnəs! kɝs ɡɑləd! hɪz ɝaɪvəl hæd ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ ə hɝ pɹaɪd, ʌv əɹ ɹɔɪəl duɾi.

Morgase watched him go, and felt her heart twist. Curse her stubbornness! Curse Galad! His arrival had reminded her of her pride, of her royal duty.

ɪt wɑz bæd fəɹ əɹ tə hæv ə hʌzbənd. ʃid lɝn ðət fɹəm tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl. fəɹ ɔl ə ðə stəbɪlɪɾi hɝ mɛɹɪdʒ tə hɪm hæd bɹɔt, itʃ ən ɛvɹi ædvæntɪdʒ hæd kʌm wɪð ə θɹɛt tə hɝ θɹoʊn. ðət wɑz waɪ ʃid nɛvɝ meɪd bɹaɪn əɹ θɔɹn əɹ əfɪʃəl kɑnsɔɹt, ən ɡeɪbɹəl oʊnli pɹuv ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ɹaɪt tə wɝi.

It was bad for her to have a husband. She'd learned that from Taringail. For all of the stability her marriage to him had brought, each and every advantage had come with a threat to her throne. That was why she'd never made Bryne or Thorn her official consort, and Gaebril only proved that she had been right to worry.

ɛni mæn u mɛɹiɾ əɹ kʊd, pətɛnʃəli, bi ə θɹɛt tə ɪleɪn əz wɛl əz ændɝ. hɝ tʃɪlʒɹən, ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛni mɔɹ, wəd bi ɹaɪvəlz tə ɪleɪnz. mɔɹɡeɪs kʊdn əfɔɹd tə lʌv.

Any man who married her could, potentially, be a threat to Elayne as well as Andor. Her children, if she had any more, would be rivals to Elayne's. Morgase couldn't afford to love.

tɑlænvɝ stɑpt ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, ən əɹ bɹɛθ kɑt. hi tɝnd, ðən wɔk bæk tə hɝ. hi dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹɾ ən bɛn daʊn, plæk-ɪŋ ɪt ɹɛvɝənli əɾ əɹ fiɾ əz ʃi stʊɾ ɪn widz ən skɹʌb.

Tallanvor stopped a short distance away, and her breath caught. He turned, then walked back to her. He drew his sword and bent down, plac-ing it reverently at her feet as she stood in weeds and scrub.

"aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ tə θɹɛɾən tə liv, bɪfɔɹ," hi sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ wɑz hɝt, ən peɪn meɪks ə mæn stupəd. jə noʊ ðəɾ əl ɔlweɪz bi hɪɹ, mɔɹɡeɪs. aɪv pɹɑməst ɪt tə jə bɪfɔɹ, ən aɪ min ɪt.

"I was wrong to threaten to leave, before," he said softly. "I was hurt, and pain makes a man stupid. You know that I will always be here, Morgase. I've promised it to you before, and I mean it.

ðiz deɪz, aɪ fil laɪk ə baɪtim ɪn ə wɝld ʌv iɡəlz. bʌɾ aɪ hæv maɪ sɔɹɾ ən maɪ hɑɹt, ən boʊθ ɑɹ jʊɹz. fɝɛvɝ."

These days, I feel like a biteme in a world of eagles. But I have my sword and my heart, and both are yours. Forever."

hi stʊd tə ɡoʊ.

He stood to go.

"tɑlænvɝ," ʃi sɛd, ɔlmoʊst ɪn ə wɪspɝ. "juv nɛvɝ æsk mi, jə noʊ. ɪf aɪ wəɾ əv ju."

"Tallanvor," she said, almost in a whisper. "You've never asked me, you know. If I would have you."

"aɪ kæn pʊt jə ɪndə ðət pəzɪʃən. ɪt wʊdn bi ɹaɪt tə fɔɹs jə tə də wʌt wi boʊθ noʊ jə mʌst, naʊ ðət juv bɪn ɪkspoʊzd."

"I can't put you into that position. It wouldn't be right to force you to do what we both know you must, now that you have been exposed."

"ænd wʌt mʌst aɪ du?"

"And what must I do?"

"tɝn mi daʊn," hi spæt, ɑbviəsli ɡɹoʊɪŋ æŋɡɹi. "fɔɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ændɝ."

"Turn me down," he spat, obviously growing angry. "For the good of Andor."

"mʌst aɪ?" ʃi æskt. "aɪ kip tɛlɪŋ maɪsɛlf ðæt, tɑlænvɝ, bʌt stɪl aɪ kwɛstʃən ɪt."

"Must I?" she asked. "I keep telling myself that, Tallanvor, but still I question it."

"wʌt ɡʊɾ æm aɪ tə ju?" hi æskt. "æt ðə vɛɹi list, jə ʃəd mɛɹi tə hɛlp ɪleɪn sɪkjʊɹ ðə lɔɪəlti ʌv wʌn ə ðə fækʃənz jə əfɛndəd."

"What good am I to you?" he asked. "At the very least, you should marry to help Elayne secure the loyalty of one of the factions you offended."

"æn soʊ aɪ ɡoʊ tə mɛɹɪdʒ wɪθaʊt lʌv," ʃi sɛd. "əɡɛn. haʊ mɛni taɪmz mʌst aɪ sækɹəfaɪs maɪ hɑɹt fəɹ ændɝ?"

"And so I go to marriage without love," she said. "Again. How many times must I sacrifice my heart for Andor?"

"æz mɛni taɪmz əz ɹikwaɪɝd, aɪ səpoʊz." hi saʊndəd soʊ bɪɾɝ, klɛntʃɪŋ ɪz fɪsts. nɑɾ æŋɡɹi ət hɝ, bʌɾ ət ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən. hi ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn ə mæn ə sətʃ pæʃən.

"As many times as required, I suppose." He sounded so bitter, clenching his fists. Not angry at her, but at the situation. He always had been a man of such passion.

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "noʊ," ʃi sɛd. "nɑɾ əɡɛn. tɑlænvɝ, lʊk ət ðət skaɪ əbʌv.

She hesitated, then shook her head. "No," she said. "Not again. Tallanvor, look at that sky above.

juv sin ðə θɪŋz ðət wɔk ðə wɝld, fɛl ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kɝsɪz stʃɹaɪk ʌs. ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə taɪm tə bi wɪθaʊt hoʊp. wɪθaʊt lʌv."

You've seen the things that walk the world, felt the Dark One's curses strike us. This is not a time to be without hope. Without love."

"bʌt wʌɾ ə duɾi?"

"But what of duty?"

"duɾi kən blʌɾi ɡt ɪn laɪn. ɪts hæɾ ɪts ʃɛɹ ə mi. ɛvɹiwʌnz hæd ðɛɹ ʃɛɹ ə mi, tɑlænvɝ.

Kevlyn nodded, then hurried off. Other woodsmen were poking through the trees, looking disturbed. Oak, ash, elm and hickory trees dying overnight was bad enough. Perrin walked back toward camp. In the distance, anvils rang. They'd bought up raw materials, every bit of iron or steel they could get from Whitebridge. The people had been eager to trade for food, and Perrin had obtained five forges, with men to move them and set them up, along with hammers, tools and coal.

Now, Neald had figured out how to make blades that wouldn't dull or break. The more he practiced, the sharper edges he was able to create. The Aiel had already begun to demand those edges for their spears, and Perrin had given Neald the order to see to them first. It was the least he owed them.

haʊɛvɝ, mɔɹɡeɪs kɑm daʊn. "aɪm sɑɹi. aɪ dɪd nɑt min tə ɪnsʌl jəɹ əθɔɹəɾi."

However, Morgase calmed down. "I'm sorry. I did not mean to insult your authority."

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz juv ɹizən tə kwɛstʃən."

"It's all right," he said. "I suppose you have reason to question."

"noʊ," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp tɔlɝ. laɪt, bʌt ʃi kəd lʊk laɪk ə kwin wən ʃi wɑntəd.

"No," Morgase said, standing up taller. Light, but she could look like a queen when she wanted.

haʊ hæd ðeɪ mɪst ɪt bɪfɔɹ? "ju ɑɹ ə lɔɹd, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. jəɹ ækʃənz ʃoʊ ɪt. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz blɛsɪd kəz ə ju, ən pɝhæps ændɝ əz wɛl. soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ɹɪmeɪn pɑɹɾ ə hɝ."

How had they missed it before? "You are a lord, Perrin Aybara. Your actions show it. The Two Rivers is blessed because of you, and perhaps Andor as well. So long as you remain part of her."

"aɪ ɪntɛn tə," pɛɹɪn pɹɑməst.

"I intend to," Perrin promised.

"wɛl, ɪf jə wəd də ðɪs θɪŋ fəɹ mi," ʃi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ tə tɑlən-vɔɹ, "ðɛn aɪ wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə spik ɑn jəɹ bɪhæf wɪð ɪleɪn. ɝeɪnʒmənts kən bi meɪd, ən taɪɾəlz - pɹɑpɝ taɪɾəlz -  kən bi bɪstoʊd."

"Well, if you would do this thing for me," she said, looking to Tallan-vor, "then I would be willing to speak on your behalf with Elayne. Arrangements can be made, and titles - proper titles -  can be bestowed."

"wi wɪl teɪk jəɹ ɔfɝ ə spikɪŋ fəɹ ʌs," feɪl sɛd, spikɪŋ kwɪkli bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn kʊd.

"We will take your offer of speaking for us," Faile said, speaking quickly before Perrin could.

"bʌt wɪl dɪsaɪd, wɪð əɹ mædʒəsti, wɛðɝ bɪstoʊɪŋ taɪɾəlz ɪz ðə . . . pɹɑpɝ kɔɹs ət ðɪs pɔɪnt."

"But we will decide, with Her Majesty, whether bestowing titles is the . . . proper course at this point."

pɛɹɪn aɪd hɝ. ʃi wɑzn stɪl kənsɪɾɝɪŋ splɪɾɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɔf ɪndə ɪts oʊn kɪŋdəm, wɑz ʃi? ðeɪd nɛvɝ dɪskʌst ɪɾ ɪn sətʃ fɹæŋk tɝmz, bʌt ʃiɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒd ɪm tə juz ðə flæɡ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən. wɛl, ðeɪɾ əv tə si əbaʊt ðæt.

Perrin eyed her. She wasn't still considering splitting the Two Rivers off into its own kingdom, was she? They'd never discussed it in such frank terms, but she'd encouraged him to use the flag of Manetheren. Well, they'd have to see about that.

nɪɹbaɪ, hi kəd si ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm, bɪɹ-leɪn - əz ɔlweɪz leɪtli - əɾ ɪz saɪd. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət mɔɹɡeɪs hæd sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ fəɹ hɪm. ɡɑləd wɑz tʌkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət. ə smɔl lɛɾɝ, ɪɾ əpɪɹd, wɪð ə ɹɛd sil. wɛɹ hæɾ i ɡɑɾən ðæt? hi lʊk tʃɹʌbəld, ðoʊ hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən laɪɾənd əz i ɝaɪvd. hi dɪdn sim sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ðə nuz ə ðə mɛɹɪdʒ;

Nearby, he could see Galad Damodred walking toward them, Bere-lain - as always lately - at his side. It appeared that Morgase had sent a messenger for him. Galad was tucking something into his pocket. A small letter, it appeared, with a red seal. Where had he gotten that? He looked troubled, though his expression lightened as he arrived. He didn't seem surprised by the news of the marriage;

hi hæɾ ə nɑd fəɹ pɛɹɪn ən ə hʌɡ fəɹ ɪz mʌðɝ, ðən ə stɝn-aɪd - bʌt kɔɹdʒəl - ɡɹiɾɪŋ fəɹ tɑlænvɝ.

he had a nod for Perrin and a hug for his mother, then a stern-eyed - but cordial - greeting for Tallanvor.

"wʌt kaɪndə sɛɹəmoʊni wəd jə laɪk?" pɛɹɪn æsk mɔɹɡeɪs. "aɪ oʊnli noʊ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz weɪ."

"What kind of ceremony would you like?" Perrin asked Morgase. "I only know the Two Rivers way."

"aɪ bɪliv sɪmpəl oʊðz bɪfɔɹ jəl səfaɪs," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "aɪm oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi taɪɝɾ ə sɛɹəmoʊni."

"I believe simple oaths before you will suffice," Morgase said. "I'm old enough to be tired of ceremony."

"saʊnz əpɹoʊpɹiət tə mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Sounds appropriate to me," Perrin said.

ɡɑləd stɛp tə ðə saɪɾ ən mɔɹɡeɪs ən tɑlænvɝ klæsp hænz. "mɑɹɾɪn tɑlænvɝ," ʃi sɛd. "aɪv hæd mɔɹ fɹəm jə ðən aɪ dɪzɝv, fəɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən aɪv noʊn ðəɾ aɪv hæɾ ɪt. juv kleɪm ðət ðə lʌv ʌv ə sɪmpəl soʊlʒɝ ɪz nʌθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə mæntəl ʌv ə kwin, bʌt ðəfɝst seɪ ðə mi-ʃʊɹ ʌv ə mæn ɪz nɑɾ ɪn ɪz taɪɾəl, bʌɾ ɪn ɪz soʊl.

Galad stepped to the side and Morgase and Tallanvor clasped hands. "Martyn Tallanvor," she said. "I've had more from you than I deserve, for longer than I've known that I've had it. You've claimed that the love of a simple soldier is nothing before the mantle of a queen, but I say the mea-sure of a man is not in his title, but in his soul.

"aɪv sin fɹəm jə bɹeɪvɝi, dɛɾəkeɪʃən, lɔɪəlti, ən lʌv. aɪv sin ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ə pɹɪns ɪnsaɪɾ ə ju, ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ə mæn u wəd ɹɪmeɪn tʃɹu wən hʌnʒɹədz ɝaʊn ɪm feɪld. aɪ swɛɹ ðəɾ aɪ lʌv ju. ən bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪt, aɪ swɛɹ nɑt tə liv ju. aɪ swɛɹ tə tʃɛɹɪʃ jə fɝɛvɝ ən əv jə əz maɪ hʌzbənd."

"I've seen from you bravery, dedication, loyalty, and love. I've seen the heart of a prince inside of you, the heart of a man who would remain true when hundreds around him failed. I swear that I love you. And before the Light, I swear not to leave you. I swear to cherish you forever and have you as my husband."

bɹəleɪn tʊk aʊɾ ə kɝtʃəf ən dæb ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz. wɛl, wɪmən ɔlweɪz wɛpt ət θɪŋz laɪk wɛɾɪŋz. ðoʊ pɛɹɪn . . . wɛl i fɛlt ə lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ ɪn ɪz aɪz, tu. maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt.

Berelain took out a kerchief and dabbed the corners of her eyes. Well, women always wept at things like weddings. Though Perrin . . . well he felt a little water in his eyes, too. Might have been the sunlight.

"mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd," tɑlænvɝ sɛd, "aɪ fɛl ɪn lʌv wɪð jə fəɹ ðə weɪ jə tʃɹiɾəd ðoʊz ɝaʊn jə əz kwin. aɪ sɔ ə wʊmən u tʊk duɾi wɪð nɑt dʒʌst ə sɛns ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, bʌt wɪð ə pæʃən. ivən wən jə dɪdnt noʊ mi fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ ɡɑɹd, jə tʃɹiɾəd mi wɪð kaɪndnəs ən ɹɪspɛkt. jə tʃɹiɾəd ɔl ə jəɹ sʌbʒɪkts ðət weɪ.

"Morgase Trakand," Tallanvor said, "I fell in love with you for the way you treated those around you as Queen. I saw a woman who took duty with not just a sense of responsibility, but with a passion. Even when you didn't know me from any other guard, you treated me with kindness and respect. You treated all of your subjects that way.

"aɪ lʌv jə fəɹ jəɹ ɡʊdnəs, jəɹ klɛvɝnəs, jəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ə maɪn ən wɪl. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən kʊdn bɹeɪk ju; jə ɪskeɪpt ɪm wən i θɔt jə kəmplitli ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. ðə moʊs tɛɹəbəl ə taɪɹəns kʊdn bɹeɪk ju, ivən wən i hɛl jə ɪn ɪz pɑm. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kʊdn bɹeɪk ju. ənʌðɝ wəd bi heɪtfəl ɪn jəɹ pleɪs, ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn θɹu wʌt jə hæd. bʌt jə . . .

"I love you for your goodness, your cleverness, your strength of mind and will. One of the Forsaken couldn't break you; you escaped him when he thought you completely under control. The most terrible of tyrants couldn't break you, even when he held you in his palm. The Shaido couldn't break you. Another would be hateful in your place, if they had been through what you had. But you . . .

juv ɡɹoʊn, ɪnkɹisɪŋli, ɪndə sʌmwʌn tə ædmaɪɹ, tʃɛɹɪʃ, ən ɹɪspɛkt.

you have grown, increasingly, into someone to admire, cherish, and respect.

"aɪ swɛɹ ðəɾ aɪ lʌv ju. ən bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪt, aɪ swɛɹ ðəɾ əl nɛvɝ, nɛvɝ liv ju. aɪ swɛɹ tə tʃɛɹɪʃ jə fɝɛvɝ ən əv jə əz maɪ waɪf. aɪ swɛɹ ɪt, mɔɹɡeɪs, ðoʊ pɑɹɾ ə mi feɪlz tə bɪliv ðət ðɪs kəd ɹɪli bi hæpənɪŋ."

"I swear that I love you. And before the Light, I swear that I will never, never leave you. I swear to cherish you forever and have you as my wife. I swear it, Morgase, though part of me fails to believe that this could really be happening."

ən ðən ðeɪ stʊd laɪk ðæt, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝz aɪz, əz ɪf pɛɹɪn wɝn ivən ðɛɹ.

And then they stood like that, staring into one another's eyes, as if Perrin weren't even there.

hi kɔft. "wɛl, soʊ bi ɪt, ðɛn. jəɹ mɛɹid." ʃəɾ i ɡɪv ædvaɪs? haʊ dɪd wʌn ɡɪv ædvaɪs tə mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, ə kwin wɪð tʃɪlʒɹən ɪz oʊn eɪdʒ? hi dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡd. "ɔf wɪð ju, ðɛn."

He coughed. "Well, so be it, then. You're married." Should he give advice? How did one give advice to Morgase Trakand, a queen with children his own age? He just shrugged. "Off with you, then."

bɪsaɪd hɪm, feɪl smɛld əmjuzd ən feɪnli dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. lini snɔɹɾɪd ət pɛɹɪnz pɝfɔɹməns, bʌɾ ʌʃɝd mɔɹɡeɪs ən tɑlænvɝ əweɪ. ɡɑləd nɑɾəd tə hɪm, ən bɹəleɪn kɝtsid. ðeɪ wɔkt əweɪ, bɹəleɪn ɹɪmɑɹkɪŋ ɑn ðə sʌɾənnəs ʌv ɪt.

Beside him, Faile smelled amused and faintly dissatisfied. Lini snorted at Perrin's performance, but ushered Morgase and Tallanvor away. Galad nodded to him, and Berelain curtsied. They walked away, Berelain remarking on the suddenness of it.

feɪl smaɪld ət hɪm. "jul əv tə ɡɛt bɛɾɝ ət ðæt."

Faile smiled at him. "You'll have to get better at that."

"ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪt sɪmpəl."

"They wanted it simple."

"ɛvɹiwʌn sɛz ðæt," feɪl ɹɪplaɪd. "bʌt jə kən əv ən ɛɹ ʌv ɔθɝ- aɪɾi waɪl kipɪŋ θɪŋz bɹif. wɪl tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt. nɛks taɪm jəl də ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ dʒɑb."

"Everyone says that," Faile replied. "But you can have an air of author- ity while keeping things brief. We'll talk about it. Next time you'll do a much better job."

nɛks taɪm? hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz feɪl tɝn ən wɔk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp.

Next time? He shook his head as Faile turned and walked toward the camp.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Where are you going?" Perrin asked.

"tə beɪvɪn. aɪ nid tə ɹɛkwəzɪʃən səm kæsks ʌv eɪl."

"To Bavin. I need to requisition some casks of ale."

"fɔɹ wʌt?"

"For what?"

"ðə fɛstɪvəɾiz," feɪl sɛd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "sɛɹəmoʊni kən bi skɪmpt ɪf niɾəd. bʌt ðə sɛləbɹeɪʃən ʃəd nɑt bi skɪmpt." ʃi ɡlænst ʌpwɝd. "pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ət taɪmz laɪk ðɪs."

"The festivities," Faile said, looking over her shoulder. "Ceremony can be skimped if needed. But the celebration should not be skimped." She glanced upward. "Particularly at times like this."

pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ, dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ɪndə ði ɪnɔɹməs kæmp. soʊlʒɝz, fɑɹmɝz, kɹæfsmən, il, waɪtkloʊks, ɹɛfjudʒiz. ɔlmoʊst sɛvənti θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ, dɪspaɪt ðoʊz u hæd lɛft əɹ fɔlən ɪn bæɾəl.

Perrin watched her go, disappearing into the enormous camp. Soldiers, farmers, craftsmen, Aiel, Whitecloaks, refugees. Almost seventy thousand strong, despite those who had left or fallen in battle.

haʊ hæɾ i ɛndəɾ ʌp wɪð sətʃ ə fɔɹs? bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, hid nɛvɝ sin mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzən pipəl ɡæðɝɾ ɪn wʌn pleɪs.

How had he ended up with such a force? Before leaving the Two Rivers, he'd never seen more than a thousand people gathered in one place.

ðə lɑɹdʒəs pɔɹʃən wɑz ðə ɡɹup ə fɔɹmɝ mɝsənɛɹiz ən ɹɛfjudʒiz u hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ʌndɝ tɑɹn ən dænɪl. ðə wʊlf ɡɑɹd, ðeɪ wɝ kɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min. pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ tə tʃɛk ɑn ðə səplaɪ kɑɹts, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ smɔl stʃɹʌk ɪm sɔfli ɑn ðə bæk ə ðə hɛd.

The largest portion was the group of former mercenaries and refugees who had been training under Tarn and Dannil. The Wolf Guard, they were calling themselves, whatever that was supposed to mean. Perrin began walking to check on the supply carts, but something small struck him softly on the back of the head.

hi fɹoʊz, tɝnɪŋ, skænɪŋ ðə fɔɹəs bɪhaɪn hɪm. tə ðə ɹaɪt, ɪt stʊd bɹaʊn ən dɛd; tə hɪz lɛft, ðə tʃɹi kʌvɝ dwɪndəld. hi kʊdn sin ɛniwʌn.

He froze, turning, scanning the forest behind him. To the right, it stood brown and dead; to his left, the tree cover dwindled. He couldn't seen anyone.

hæv aɪ bɪn pʊʃɪŋ maɪsɛlf tu hɑɹd? hi wʌndɝd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əz i tɝn tə kəntɪnju wɔkɪŋ. ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz ðət -  ənʌðɝ lɪɾəl stʃɹaɪk ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. hi spʌn ən kɑt saɪɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ dʒɹɑpɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹæs. fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi nɛl daʊn ən pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp. ən eɪkɔɹn. ənʌðɝ wʌn smækt ɪm ɪn ðə fɔɹhɛd.

Have I been pushing myself too hard? he wondered, rubbing his head as he turned to continue walking. Imagining things that -  Another little strike on the back of his head. He spun and caught sight of something dropping to the grass. Frowning, he knelt down and picked it up. An acorn. Another one smacked him in the forehead.

ɪt hæd kʌm fɹəm ðə fɔɹəst.

It had come from the forest.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz. wʌn ə ðə kæmps fju tʃɪlʒɹən, pɝhæps? əhɛd wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ oʊk tʃɹi; ðə tʃɹʌŋk θɪk ən waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə haɪd sʌmwʌn. wʌns i ɡɹu kloʊs, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Perrin growled and strode into the trees. One of the camp's few children, perhaps? Ahead was a large oak tree; the trunk thick and wide enough to hide someone. Once he grew close, he hesitated.

wɑz ðɪs səm kaɪndə tʃɹæp? hi leɪɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz hæmɝ ən ɪntʃt fɔɹwɝd. ðə tʃɹi wɑz daʊnwɪnd, ən i kʊdn kætʃ ðə sɛn ʌv -  ə hæn sʌɾənli dʒʌɾɪd aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɹʌŋk, hoʊldɪŋ ə bɹaʊn sæk. "aɪ kɑɾ ə bædʒɝ," ə fəmɪljɝ vɔɪs sɛd. "wɑn tə lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ ɑn ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɹin?"

Was this some kind of trap? He laid his hand on his hammer and inched forward. The tree was downwind, and he couldn't catch the scent of -  A hand suddenly jutted out from behind the trunk, holding a brown sack. "I caught a badger," a familiar voice said. "Want to let it go on the village green?"

pɛɹɪn fɹoʊz, ðən lɛɾ aʊɾ ə bɛloʊɪŋ læf. hi ɹaʊndəd ðə tʃɹiz tʃɹʌŋk ən faʊn ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn ə haɪ-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊt - tʃɹɪmd wɪð ɡoʊld - ən faɪn bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə tʃɹiz ɪkspoʊzd ɹuts, ðə sæk skwɝmɪŋ nɪɹ ɪz æŋkəlz. mæt wɑz tʃuɪŋ aɪdli ɑn ə lɔŋ lɛŋθ ə dʒɝk. ən wɔɹ ə bɹɔd-bɹɪm blæk hæt. ə blæk pɑlɹm wɪð ə bɹɔd bleɪɾ ət ðə tɑp lin əɡɛns ðə tʃɹi bɪsaɪd hɪm. wɛɹ hæɾ i ɡɑɾən sətʃ faɪn kloʊðɪŋ? hædn i wʌns kəmpleɪn əbaʊt ɹænd wɛɹɪŋ aʊtfɪts laɪk ðæt?

Perrin froze, then let out a bellowing laugh. He rounded the tree's trunk and found a figure in a high-collared red coat - trimmed with gold - and fine brown trousers sitting on the tree's exposed roots, the sack squirming near his ankles. Mat was chewing idly on a long length of jerk. and wore a broad-brimmed black hat. A black polearm with a broad blade at the top leaned against the tree beside him. Where had he gotten such fine clothing? Hadn't he once complained about Rand wearing outfits like that?

"mæt?" pɛɹɪn æskt, nɪɹli tu stʌn tə spik. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?"

"Mat?" Perrin asked, nearly too stunned to speak. "What are you doing here?"

"kætʃɪŋ bædʒɝz," mæt sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə sæk. "blʌɾi hɑɹd tə du, jə noʊ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɑn ʃɔɹt noʊɾəs."

"Catching badgers," Mat said, shaking the sack. "Bloody hard to do, you know, particularly on short notice."

ðə sæk ɹʌsəld ən pɛɹɪn hɝɾ ə feɪnt ɡɹaʊl fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. hi kəd smɛl ðət ðəɹ wɑz, ɪndid, sʌmθɪŋ əlaɪv ɪn ðət sæk. "ju æktʃəli  kɑt wʌn?"

The sack rustled and Perrin heard a faint growl from inside. He could smell that there was, indeed, something alive in that sack. "You actually caught one?"

"kɔl mi nɔstælʒɪk."

"Call me nostalgic."

pɛɹɪn dɪdnt noʊ wɛðɝ tə tʃæstaɪz mæt əɹ læf əɾ ɪm - ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ mɪks ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz wɑz kɑmən wən mæt wɑz ɝaʊnd. noʊ kʌlɝz, fɔɹtʃənətli, spʌn ɪn pɛɹɪnz aɪz naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ nɪɹ wʌn ənʌðɝ. laɪt, ðət wʊɾə bɪn kənfjuzɪŋ. pɛɹɪn dɪd fil ə . . . taɪtnəs, haʊɛvɝ.

Perrin didn't know whether to chastise Mat or laugh at him - that particular mix of emotions was common when Mat was around. No colors, fortunately, spun in Perrin's eyes now that they were near one another. Light, that would have been confusing. Perrin did feel a . . . Tightness, however.

ðə lɔŋ-lɪmd mæn smaɪld, sɛɾɪŋ ðə sæk daʊn ən stændɪŋ, ɔfɝɪŋ ə hænd. pɛɹɪn tʊk ɪt, bʌt pʊl mæt ɪndə ə hɑɹɾi hʌɡ.

The long-limbed man smiled, setting the sack down and standing, offering a hand. Perrin took it, but pulled Mat into a hearty hug.

"laɪt, mæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪt simz laɪk ɪts bɪn fɝɛvɝ!"

"Light, Mat," Perrin said. "It seems like its been forever!"

"ə laɪftaɪm," mæt sɛd. "meɪbi tu. aɪ luz kaʊnt. ɛniweɪ, keɪɛmlɪn ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪz bʌzɪŋ wɪð nuz ə jəɹ ɝaɪvəl. fɪɡjɝd ði oʊnli weɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn ə wɝɾ ʌv wɛlkəm wɑz tə slɪp θɹu ðət ɡeɪtweɪ ən faɪn jə bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls." mæt pɪkt ʌp ɪz spɪɹ ən ɹɛstəɾ ɪɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bleɪd tə ðə bæk.

"A lifetime," Mat said. "Maybe two. I lose count. Anyway, Caemlyn is already is buzzing with news of your arrival. Figured the only way to get in a word of welcome was to slip through that gateway and find you before everyone else." Mat picked up his spear and rested it on his shoulder, blade to the back.

"wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ? wɛɹ əv jə bɪn? ɪz tɑm wɪð ju? wʌɾ əbaʊt nɪneɪiv?"

"What have you been doing? Where have you been? Is Thom with you? What about Nynaeve?"

"soʊ mɛni kwɛstʃənz," mæt sɛd. "haʊ seɪf ɪz ðɪs kæmp ə jʊɹz?"

"So many questions," Mat said. "How safe is this camp of yours?"

"seɪf əz ɛni pleɪs."

"Safe as any place."

"nɑt seɪf ɪnʌf," mæt ɡɹu sɑləm. "lʊk, pɛɹɪn, wiv ɡɑt səm maɪɾi deɪnʒɝəs foʊks æftɝ ʌs. aɪ keɪm kəz aɪ wɑntəd tə wɔɹn jə tə teɪk ɛkstʃɹə kɛɹ. əsæsənz wɪl faɪn jə sun ɪnʌf, ən jud bɛs bi ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðɛm. wi nid tə kætʃ ʌp. bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑnə də ɪt hɪɹ."

"Not safe enough," Mat grew solemn. "Look, Perrin, we've got some mighty dangerous folks after us. I came because I wanted to warn you to take extra care. Assassins will find you soon enough, and you'd best be ready for them. We need to catch up. But I don't want to do it here."

"wɛɹ, ðɛn?"

"Where, then?"

"mit mi ɪn ən ɪn kɔl ðə hæpi θɹɔŋ, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. oʊ, ən ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd, əl bi wɑntɪŋ tə bɑɹoʊ wʌn ə ðoʊz blæk-koʊɾəd fɛloʊz ə jʊɹz fəɹ ə fju ʃeɪks. niɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ."

"Meet me in an inn called The Happy Throng, in Caemlyn. Oh, and if you don't mind, I'll be wanting to borrow one of those black-coated fellows of yours for a few shakes. Need a gateway."

"fɔɹ wʌt pɝpəs?"

"For what purpose?"

"aɪl ɪkspleɪn. bʌt leɪɾɝ." mæt tɪpt ɪz hæt, tɝnɪŋ tə dʒɑɡ bæk təwɔɹd ðə stɪl-oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn. "ɹɪli," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ən dʒɑmɡ bækwɝd fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

"I'll explain. But later." Mat tipped his hat, turning to jog back toward the still-open gateway to Caemlyn. "Really," he said, turning and joggmg backward for a moment.

"bi kɛɹfəl, pɛɹɪn." wɪð ti hæɾ i dʌk pæst ə fju ɹɛfjudʒiz ən θtʌ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

"Be careful, Perrin." With t hat he ducked past a few refugees and thtough the gateway.

haʊ hæɾ i ɡɑɾən pæst ɡɹeɪɾi? laɪt! pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd tə hɪmsɛlf, ðən bɛn tə əntaɪ ðə sæk ən iz ðə pʊɹ bædʒɝ mæt hæd kæptʃɝd.

How had he gotten past Grady? Light! Perrin shook his head to himself, then bent to untie the sack and ease the poor badger Mat had captured.

eɪ ɹiunjən


A Reunion

ɪleɪn woʊk ɪn əɹ bɛd, blɪɹi-aɪd. "ɛɡwin?" ʃi sɛd, dɪsɔɹiɛntɪd. "wʌt?" ðə læs mɛmɹiz ə ðə dʒɹim wɝ dɪzɔlvɪŋ laɪk hʌni kənsum baɪ wɔɹm ti, bʌɾ ɛɡwin ɛs wɝdz ɹɪmeɪn fɝm ɪn ɪleɪnz maɪnd. ðə sɝpən əz fɔlən, ɛɡwin hæd sɛnt. jəɹ bɹʌðɝz ɹɪtɝn wɑz taɪmli.

Elayne woke in her bed, bleary-eyed. "Egwene?" she said, disoriented. "What?" The last memories of the dream were dissolving like honey consumed by warm tea, but Egwene s words remained firm in Elayne's mind. The serpent has fallen, Egwene had sent. Your brother's return was timely.

ɪleɪn sæɾ ʌp, filɪŋ ə sɝdʒ ə ɹɪlif. ʃi hæd spɛn ði ɪntaɪɝ naɪt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃænəl ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝk, tə noʊ əveɪl. wən ʃid faʊn aʊt ðət bɝdʒɪt hæd tɝn əweɪ ɡɔɪn - waɪl ɪleɪn sæɾ ɪnsaɪd, fjʊɹiəs bʌɾ əneɪbəl tə ətɛn ðə miɾɪŋ wɪð ɛɡwin -  ʃid bɪn lɪvɪd.

Elayne sat up, feeling a surge of relief. She had spent the entire night trying to channel enough to make her dream ter'angreal work, to no avail. When she'd found out that Birgitte had turned away Gawyn - while Elayne sat inside, furious but unable to attend the meeting with Egwene -  she'd been livid.

wɛl, mɛsænə hæd bɪn dɪfiɾəd, ɪt simd. ən wʌt wɑz ðəɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ bɹʌðɝ? ʃi smaɪld.

Well, Mesaana had been defeated, it seemed. And what was that about her brother? She smiled.

pɝhæps i ən ɛɡwin hæd wɝkt aʊt ðɛɹ pɹɑbləmz.

Perhaps he and Egwene had worked out their problems.

mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt pik θɹu ðə dʒɹeɪps. ɪleɪn sæt bæk, filɪŋ ðə paʊɝfəl wɔɹmθ θɹu ðə bɑnd wɪð ɹænd ðət hæɾ əpɪɹd ðɛɹ. laɪt, bʌt ðət wɑz ə wʌndɝfəl sɛnseɪʃən. ðə moʊmənt ʃid bɪɡʌn filɪŋ ɪt, ðə klaʊd kʌvɝ ɝaʊn ændɝ hæd bɹoʊkən.

Morning light peeked through the drapes. Elayne sat back, feeling the powerful warmth through the bond with Rand that had appeared there. Light, but that was a wonderful sensation. The moment she'd begun feeling it, the cloud cover around Andor had broken.

ɪt hæd bɪn əbaʊɾ ə wik sɪns ðə tɛstɪŋ ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz, ən ʃid pʊɾ ɔl ə ðə bɛlfndɝz ɪn əɹ neɪʃən tə wɝk ɑn kɹieɪɾɪŋ ðɛm. ðiz deɪz, wʌn kəd hɪɹ ə stɛɾi saʊn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɹɪpiɾɪŋ bumz əz mɛmbɝz əɹ ðə bæn tʃɹeɪnd wɪð ðə wɛpənz ɪn ðə hɪlz aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. soʊ fɑɹ, ʃi hæd lɛɾ oʊnli ə fju ʌv ðə wɛpənz bi juz fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ; ðə dɪfɹən timz ɹoʊteɪɾɪd pɹæktəsɪŋ ɑn ðɛm.

It had been about a week since the testing of the dragons, and she'd put all of the bellfounders in her nation to work on creating them. These days, one could hear a steady sound in Caemlyn, repeating booms as members or the Band trained with the weapons in the hills outside of the city. So far, she had let only a few of the weapons be used for training; the different teams rotated practicing on them.

ʃid ɡæðɝd ðə lɑɹdʒɝ nʌmbɝ ɪn ə sikɹət wɛɹhaʊs ɪnsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn fəɹ seɪfkipɪŋ.

She'd gathered the larger number in a secret warehouse inside Caemlyn for safekeeping.

ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt ðə dʒɹim sɛndɪŋ əɡɛn. ʃi hʌŋɡɝd fəɹ spɪsɪfɪks. wɛl, ɛɡwin wəd pɹɑbli sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ ɪvɛntʃəwəli.

She thought about the dream sending again. She hungered for specifics. Well, Egwene would probably send a messenger by gateway eventually.

ðə dɔɹ kɹækt, ən mɛlfən lʊkt ɪn. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti?" ðə ʃɔɹt, ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən æskt.

The door cracked, and Melfane looked in. "Your Majesty?" the short, round-faced woman asked.

"ɪz ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɔl ɹaɪt? aɪ θɔɾ aɪ hɝɾ ə kɹaɪ ʌv peɪn." ɛvɝ sɪns lɪftɪŋ əɹ bæn ɑn ɪleɪn ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn bɛd, ðə mɪdwaɪf hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə slip ɪn ði æntətʃæmbɝ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪleɪnz bɛdʒɹum tə kip ə kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ ɑn hɝ.

"Is everything all right? I thought I heard a cry of pain." Ever since lifting her ban on Elayne remaining in bed, the midwife had decided to sleep in the antechamber outside Elayne's bedroom to keep a careful watch on her.

"ðæt wɑz ən ɛkskləmeɪʃən ə dʒɔɪ, mɛlfən," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ə ɡɹiɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə wʌndɝfəl mɔɹnɪŋ ðəɾ əz kʌm tə ʌs."

"That was an exclamation of joy, Melfane," Elayne said. "A greeting for the wonderful morning that has come to us."

mɛlfən fɹaʊnd. ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd tə æk tʃɪɹfəl ɝaʊn ðə wʊmən, tə pɝsweɪɾ əɹ ðət mɔɹ bɛd ɹɛst wɑznt niɾəd, bʌt pɝhæps ðət læs pɑɹt hæd bɪn ə lɪɾəl mʌtʃ. ɪleɪn kʊdn əfɔɹd tə əpɪɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə bi hæpi. ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz. ɪnsʌfɝəbəl wʊmən.

Melfane frowned. Elayne tried to act cheerful around the woman, to persuade her that more bed rest wasn't needed, but perhaps that last part had been a little much. Elayne couldn't afford to appear as if she were forcing herself to be happy. Even if she was. Insufferable woman.

mɛlfən wɔkt ɪn ən pʊld oʊpən ðə dʒɹeɪps - sʌnlaɪt wɑz ɡʊd fəɹ ə wʊmən wɪð tʃaɪld, ʃiɾ ɪkspleɪnd. pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪleɪnz tʃɹitmən leɪtli hæd bɪn tə sɪɾ ɪn əɹ bɛd wɪð ðə kʌvɝz dʒɹɔn bæk, lɛɾɪŋ ðə spɹɪŋ sʌnlaɪt beɪk əɹ skɪn. əz mɛlfən muvd, ɪleɪn fɛlt ə lɪɾəl tʃɹɛmbəl fɹəm ɪnsaɪd.

Melfane walked in and pulled open the drapes - sunlight was good for a woman with child, she'd explained. Part of Elayne's treatment lately had been to sit in her bed with the covers drawn back, letting the spring sunlight bake her skin. As Melfane moved, Elayne felt a little tremble from inside.

"oʊ! ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ. ðəɹ kɪkɪŋ, mɛlfən! kʌm fil!"

"Oh! There was another. They're kicking, Melfane! Come feel!"

"aɪ woʊn bi eɪbəl tə fil ɪt jɛt, jəɹ mædʒəsti. nɑɾ əntɪl ðəɹ stʃɹɔŋɝ." ʃi bɪɡæn ðə nɔɹməl deɪli ɹutin. lɪsən tə ɪleɪnz hɑɹtbit, ðən lɪsən fəɹ ðə beɪbz. mɛlfən stɪl wʊdn bɪliv ðəɹ wɝ twɪnz. æftɝ ðæt, ʃi ɪnspɛktɪɾ ən pɹɑɾɪd ɪleɪn, pɝfɔɹmɪŋ ɔl ə ðə tɛsts ɪn əɹ sikɹəɾɪv lɪst ʌv ənɔɪɪŋ ən ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ θɪŋz tə də tə wɪmən.

"I won't be able to feel it yet, Your Majesty. Not until they're stronger." She began the normal daily routine. Listen to Elayne's heartbeat, then listen for the babe's. Melfane still wouldn't believe there were twins. After that, she inspected and prodded Elayne, performing all of the tests in her secretive list of annoying and embarrassing things to do to women.

faɪnəli, mɛlfən pleɪs hænz ɑn hɪps, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪleɪn, hu wɑz duɪŋ ʌp əɹ naɪtɡaʊn. "aɪ θɪŋk juv bɪn stʃɹeɪnɪŋ jɝsɛlf tu mʌtʃ leɪtli. aɪ wɑn jə tə bi sɝɾən tə teɪk pɹɑpɝ ɹɛst. maɪ kʌzən tɛsəz dɔɾɝ hæɾ ə tʃaɪl nɑt tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ hu wɑz bɝθɛd bɛɹli bɹiðɪŋ. laɪt bi θæŋk ðət ðə tʃaɪl sɝvaɪvd, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ ðə filz leɪt θɹu ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ ən nɑt teɪkɪŋ pɹɑpɝ milz. ɪmædʒən! teɪk kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf, maɪ kwin. jəɹ beɪbiz wɪl bi θæŋkfəl fəɹ ɪt."

Finally, Melfane placed hands on hips, regarding Elayne, who was doing up her nightgown. "I think you've been straining yourself too much lately. I want you to be certain to take proper rest. My cousin Tess's daughter had a child not two years ago who was birthed barely breathing. Light be thanked that the child survived, but she had been working the fields late through the day before and not taking proper meals. Imagine! Take care of yourself, my Queen. Your babies will be thankful for it."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd, ɹɪlæksɪŋ. "weɪt!" ʃi sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp. "beɪbiz?"

Elayne nodded, relaxing. "Wait!" she said, sitting up. "Babies?"

"Yes," Melfane said, walking to the door. "There are two heartbeats in your womb, sure as I have two arms. Don't know how you knew it."

"ju hɝd ðə hɑɹtbits!" ɪleɪn ɪkskleɪmd, ɪleɪɾəd. jɛs, ðəɹ ðɛɹ, ʃʊɹ əz ðə sʌn."

"You heard the heartbeats!" Elayne exclaimed, elated. Yes, they're there, sure as the sun."

mɛlfən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən lɛft, sɛndɪŋ ɪn nɛɹɪs ən sɛfæni tə dʒɹɛs əɹ ən bɹʌʃ əɹ hɛɹ.

Melfane shook her head and left, sending in Naris and Sephanie to dress her and brush her hair.

ɪleɪn ɛndʒjʊɹd ðə pɹɑsɛs ɪn ə steɪɾ ʌv əmeɪzmənt. mɛlfən bɪlivd! ʃi kʊdn stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm smaɪlɪŋ.

Elayne endured the process in a state of amazement. Melfane believed! She couldn't stop herself from smiling.

ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, ʃi sɛɾəld ɪndə hɝ smɔl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wɪndoʊz ɔl θɹoʊn oʊpən tə lɛɾ ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt, sɪpɪŋ wɔɹm ɡoʊts mɪlk. mæstɝ nɔɹi ɛntɝɾ ɑn lɔŋ spɪnli lɛɡz, tʌfs ə hɛɹ stɪkɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪn ðə bæks ə hɪz ɪɹz, feɪs lɔŋ ən pikt, lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm i wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ daɪɛlɪn, hu dɪdn juʒəwəli ətɛn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ mit-ɪŋ. ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə wʊmən.

An hour later, she settled into her small sitting room, windows all thrown open to let in the sunlight, sipping warm goat's milk. Master Norry entered on long spindly legs, tufts of hair sticking up behind the backs of his ears, face long and peaked, leather folder under his arm He was accompanied by Dyelin, who didn't usually attend the morning meet-ing. Elayne raised an eyebrow at the woman.

"aɪ hæv ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən jə ɹɪkwɛstɪd, ɪleɪn," daɪɛlɪn sɛd, pɔɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf səm mɔɹnɪŋ ti.

"I have the information you requested, Elayne," Dyelin said, pouring herself some morning tea.

tədeɪ ɪt wɑz klaʊdbɛɹi. "aɪ hɪɹ mɛlfən hɝd hɑɹtbits?"

Today it was cloudberry. "I hear Melfane heard heartbeats?"

"ʃi dɪɾ ɪndid."

"She did indeed."

hi ɔlsoʊ tɔkt ə fud pɹɑbləmz. dɪspaɪt ðə kɪnswɪmən meɪkɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz tə ɹændz lænz tə ðə saʊθ fəɹ səplaɪ - ən dɪspaɪt ðə kæʃɪz ʌv ʌnɪkspɛktɪd fud stɔɹz ðət hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi - keɪɛmlɪn wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ loʊ.

None of the three Houses whose nobility had been captured could afford to pay ransom. Once the Arawn, Sarand and Marne estates had been among the most productive and extensive in Andor - and now they were destitute, their coffers dry, their fields barren. And Elayne had left two of them without leadership. Light, what a mess!

nɔɹi muvd ɑn. ʃi hæɾ ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm tælmɑnz, əɡɹiɪŋ tə muv sɛvɹəl kʌmpəniz ə soʊlʒɝz fɹəm ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hæn tə kɛɹhin. ʃi ɔɹɾɝd nɔɹi tə sɛn ɪm ə ɹɪt wɪð əɹ sil, ɔθɝaɪzɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz tə "lɛn eɪd ɹɪstɔɹɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ." ðət wɑz, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑnsɛns. noʊ ɔɹɾɝ niɾəd tə bi ɹɪstɔɹd. bʌɾ ɪf ɪleɪn wɑz ɛvɝ gɑnə muv fəɹ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, ʃid nid tə meɪk səm pɹɪlɪmənɛɹi muvz ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən.

ðɪs ɪz kɛɹhin, æftɝ ɔl."

Daes Dae mar. Yes, it would make sense for Rand's allies to resist her ascent to the throne. Those who had been favored by Rand would be favored for the throne, should Elayne prove incapable.

She owed much to Dyelin, who seemed to have taken it upon herself to act as a surrogate mother to Elayne. A voice of experience and wisdom. But eventually, Dyelin would have to take a few steps back. "This will be for the best," Elayne said firmly, to distract attention f rom her treacherous eyes.

"aɪm stɪl wɝiɾ əbaʊt ði ɪnveɪʒən."

"I'm still worried about the invasion."

daɪɛlɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ tə ðæt. ʃi dɪdn bɪliv ðət tʃɛzməl hæd bɪn tɔkɪŋ ʌv ə spəsɪfɪk ɪnveɪʒən ʌv ændɝ; ʃi θɔt ðət ðə blæk sɪstɝ hæd bɪn spikɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɪnveɪʒən ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. bɝdʒɪt tʊk ðə nuz mɔɹ sɪɹiəsli, bifɪŋ ʌp soʊlʒɝz ɑn ði ændɔɝən bɔɹɾɝz.

Dyelin said nothing to that. She didn't believe that Chesmal had been talking of a specific invasion of Andor; she thought that the Black sister had been speaking of the Trolloc invasion of the Borderlands. Birgitte took the news more seriously, beefing up soldiers on the Andoran borders.

stɪl, ɛɡwin wəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk tə hæv kəntʃɹoʊl ə kɛɹhin; ɪf tʃɹɑləks wɝ tə mɑɹtʃ ɑn ændɝ, θɹu hɝ sɪstɝ ɹɛlm wəd bi wʌn ə ði ævənuz ðeɪ maɪt juz.

Still, Egwene would very much like to have control of Cairhien; if Trollocs were to march on Andor, through her sister realm would be one of the avenues they might use.

bɪfɔɹ ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən kəd ɡoʊ fɝðɝ, ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔlweɪ oʊpənd, ən ɪleɪn wʊɾə dʒʌmpt ɪn əlɑɹm hæd ʃi nɑt fɛl ðəɾ ɪt wɑz bɝdʒɪt. ðə wɔɹɾɝ nɛvɝ nɑkt. ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn, wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd -  ɹɪlʌktənli - ən əɹ ni-haɪ blæk buts oʊvɝ tʃɹaʊzɝz. ɑdli, ʃi wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ tu kloʊk fɪɡjɝz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən baɪ hʊdz. nɔɹi stɛp bæk, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə hɪz bɹɛst ət ði ɪɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi ʌv ɪt. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðəɾ ɪleɪn dɪdn laɪk tə si vɪzəɾɝz ɪn ðə smɔl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ɪf bɝdʒɪt wɑz bɹɪŋɪŋ pipəl hɪɹ. . . .

Before the conversation could go further, the door to the hallway opened, and Elayne would have jumped in alarm had she not felt that it was Birgitte. The Warder never knocked. She strode in, wearing a sword -  reluctantly - and her knee-high black boots over trousers. Oddly, she was followed by two cloaked figures, their faces hidden by hoods. Norry stepped back, raising a hand to his breast at the irregularity of it. Everyone knew that Elayne didn't like to see visitors in the small sitting room. If Birgitte was bringing people here. . . .

"mæt?" ɪleɪn ɡɛst.

"Mat?" Elayne guessed.

"hɑɹdli," ə fəmɪljɝ vɔɪs sɛd, fɝm ən klɪɹ. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ə ðə fɪɡjɝz loʊɝɾ ɪz hʊd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə pɝfəkli bjuɾəfəl mæskjələn feɪs. hi hæɾ ə skwɛɹ dʒɔ ən ə sɛɾ ə foʊkəst aɪz ðəɾ ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd wɛl fɹəm əɹ tʃaɪldhʊd - moʊsli wən i hæd noʊɾəst əɹ duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ.

"Hardly," a familiar voice said, firm and clear. The larger of the figures lowered his hood, revealing a perfectly beautiful masculine face. He had a square jaw and a set of focused eyes that Elayne remembered well from her childhood - mostly when he had noticed her doing something wrong.

"ɡɑləd," ɪleɪn sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə wɔɹmθ ʃi fɛl fəɹ əɹ hæf-bɹʌðɝ. ʃi ɹoʊz, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ hænz təwɔɹd hɪm. ʃid spɛn moʊst ə ðɛɹ tʃaɪldhʊd fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd wɪð ɪm fəɹ wʌn ɹizən əɹ ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si hɪm əlaɪv ən wɛl. "wɛɹ əv jə bɪn?"

"Galad," Elayne said, surprised at the warmth she felt for her half-brother. She rose, holding out her hands toward him. She'd spent most of their childhood frustrated with him for one reason or another, but it was good to see him alive and well. "Where have you been?"

"aɪ hæv bɪn sikɪŋ tʃɹuθ," ɡɑləd sɛd boʊɪŋ wɪð ən ɛkspɝt baʊ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ əpɹoʊtʃ tə teɪk əɹ hænz. hi ɹoʊz ən ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd. "aɪ faʊn ðət wɪtʃ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt. stil jɝsɛlf, sɪstɝ."

"I have been seeking truth," Galad said bowing with an expert bow, but he did not approach to take her hands. He rose and glanced to the side. "I found that which I did not expect. Steel yourself, sister."

ɪleɪn fɹaʊn əz ðə sɛkənd, ʃɔɹɾɝ fɪɡjɝ loʊɝɾ əɹ hʊd. ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ.

Elayne frowned as the second, shorter figure lowered her hood. Elayne's mother.

ɪleɪn ɡæspt. ɪt wɑz hɝ! ðət feɪs, ðət ɡoʊldən hɛɹ. ðoʊz aɪz ðət hæd soʊ ɔfən lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn əz ə tʃaɪld, dʒʌdʒɪŋ hɝ, mɛʒɝɪŋ əɹ - nɑt mɪɹli əz ə pɛɹən mɛʒɝɾ əɹ dɔɾɝ, bʌɾ əz ə kwin mɛʒɝɾ əɹ səksɛsɝ. ɪleɪn fɛlt əɹ hɑɹt biɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ tʃɛst. hɝ mʌðɝ. hɝ mʌðɝ wɑz əlaɪv.

Elayne gasped. It was her! That face, that golden hair. Those eyes that had so often looked at Elayne as a child, judging her, measuring her - not merely as a parent measured her daughter, but as a queen measured her successor. Elayne felt her heart beating in her chest. Her mother. Her mother was alive.

mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz əlaɪv. ðə kwin stɪl lɪvd.

Morgase was alive. The Queen still lived.

mɔɹɡeɪs lɑkt aɪz wɪð ɪleɪn, ðən - ɑdli - mɔɹɡeɪs lʊk daʊn. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə kɝtsi, stɪl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ.

Morgase locked eyes with Elayne, then - oddly - Morgase looked down. "Your Majesty," she said with a curtsy, still remaining beside the door.

ɪleɪn kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ θɔts, kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ pænɪk. ʃi wɑz kwin, əɹ ʃi wʊɾə bɪn kwin, əɹ . . . laɪt! ʃid teɪkən ðə θɹoʊn, ən ʃi wɑz ət lis ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. bʌt naʊ hɝ oʊnsɛvən

Elayne controlled her thoughts, controlled her panic. She was Queen, or she would have been Queen, or . . . Light! She'd taken the throne, and she was at least the Daughter-Heir. But now her own7

mʌðɝ keɪm bæk fɹəm ðə blʌɾi dɛd?

mother came back from the bloody dead?

"Please, sit," Elayne found herself saying, gesturing Morgase toward the seat beside Dyelin. It did Elayne good to see that Dyelin wasn't dealing with the shock any better than Elayne. She sat with her hand gripping her cup of tea, knuckles white, eyes bulging.

"θæŋk ju, jəɹ mædʒəsti," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd, wɔkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ɡɑləd dʒɔɪnɪŋ əɹ ən ɹɛstɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪleɪnz ʃoʊldɝ ɪn ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ weɪ. hi ðən fɛtʃt hɪmsɛlf ə sit fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum.

mɔɹɡeɪsəz toʊn wɑz mɔɹ ɹɪzɝv ðən ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ən waɪ dɪd ʃi kəntɪnju tə kɔl ɪleɪn ðət taɪɾəl? ðə kwin hæd kʌm ɪn sikɹət, wɪð hʊd dʒɹɔn. ɪleɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ mʌðɝ, pʊɾɪŋ ðə pisəz təɡɛðɝ əz ʃi sæt. "ju ɹɪnaʊns ðə θɹoʊn, dɪdn ju?"

Morgase's tone was more reserved than Elayne remembered. And why did she continue to call Elayne that title? The Queen had come in secret, with hood drawn. Elayne regarded her mother, putting the pieces together as she sat. "You renounced the throne, didn't you?"

mɔɹɡeɪs ɡeɪv ə steɪtli nɑd.

Morgase gave a stately nod.

"Oh, thank the Light," Dyelin said, letting out a loud breath, hand raised to her breast. "No offense, Morgase. But for a moment there, I imagined a war between Trakand and Trakand!"

"It wouldn't have come to that," Elayne said, virtually at the same time that her mother said something similar. Their eyes met, and Elayne allowed herself to smile. "We would have found a . . .

ɹizənəbəl əkɑmədeɪʃən. ðɪs wɪl du, ðoʊ aɪ sɝɾənli wʌndɝ ət ðə sɝkəmstænsəz ə ði ɪvɛnt."

reasonable accommodation. This will do, though I certainly wonder at the circumstances of the event."

"Bloody Whitecloaks," Elayne muttered under her breath. Light, they'd actually been telling the truth when they'd written, claiming to have Morgase in their possession?

ɪleɪn blɪŋkt, ðən ɡlænst ət mɔɹɡeɪs. ði ɛldɝ tʃɹəkənd nɑɾəd. ."wɛl," ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪ si wɪv mʌtʃ tə kætʃ ʌp ɑn."

Galad took that as a request - he could be very literal - and began explaining how he'd come by his station. He was quite detailed about it, and Elayne occasionally glanced at her mother. Morgase's expression was unreadable.

wʌns ɡɑləd wɑz dʌn, hi æskt æftɝ ðə səksɛʃən wɔɹ. kənvɝsɪŋ wɪð ɡɑləd wɑz ɔfən laɪk ðɪs: ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, mɔɹ fɔɹməl ðən fəmɪljɝ. wʌns, ɪt hæd fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd hɝ, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ʃi faʊn ðət -  əɡɛnst əɹ bɛɾɝ wɪʃɪz - ʃiɾ æktʃəli  bɪn mɪsɪŋ hɪm. soʊ ʃi lɪsənd wɪð fɑndnəs.

Once Galad was done, he asked after the Succession war. Conversing with Galad was often like this: an exchange, more formal than familiar. Once, it had frustrated her, but this time she found that -  against her better wishes - she'd actually been missing him. So she listened with fondness.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən waʊn daʊn. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt wɪð hɪm, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz daɪɪŋ fəɹ ə tʃæns tə spik dʒʌst wɪð əɹ mʌðɝ. "ɡɑləd," ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪd laɪk tə tɔk fɝðɝ.

Eventually, the conversation wound down. There was more to talk about with him, but Elayne was dying for a chance to speak just with her mother. "Galad," Elayne said, "I'd like to talk further.

wəd jə bi əmɛnəbəl tə ən ɝli dɪnɝ ðɪs ivnɪŋ? jə meɪ teɪk ɹəfɹɛʃmən ɪn jəɹ oʊl kɔɹɾɝz əntɪl ðɛn."

Would you be amenable to an early dinner this evening? You may take refreshment in your old quarters until then."

hi nɑɾəd, stændɪŋ. "ðæt wəd bi wɛl."

daɪɛlɪn nɑɾəd. ʃi ɡlænst ət mɔɹɡeɪs - daɪɛlɪn wɑznt wʌn ə ðoʊz hum ðə fɔɹmɝ kwin hæɾ ɪmbɛɹəs dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz ə ɹɑvɪn ɛs ɪnfluəns, bʌt ʃi hæɾ əndaʊɾɪdli hɝd ðə stɔɹiz. ðən daɪɛlɪn wɪθdʒɹu wɪð ɡɑləɾ ən mæstɝ nɔɹi. mɔɹɡeɪs ɡlænst ət bɝdʒɪɾ əz sun əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd; ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ði oʊnli ʌðɝ wʌn ɪn ðə ɹum.

"aɪ tʃɹʌst əɹ laɪk ə sɪstɝ, mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "æn ɪnsʌfɝəbəl oʊldɝ sɪstɝ, səmtaɪmz, bʌɾ ə sɪstɝ nʌnðəlɛs."

Morgase smiled, then rose and took Elayne by the hands, pulling her up into an embrace. "Ah, my daughter," she said, tears in her eyes. "Look at what you've done! Queen in your own right!"

jə tʃɹeɪn mi wɛl, mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. ʃi pʊl bæk. "æn jə ɹeɪ ə ɡɹændmʌðɝ! əɹ sun wɪl bi!"

You trained me well, Mother," Elayne said. She pulled back. "And you re a grandmother! Or soon will be!"

mɔɹɡeɪs fɹaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ. "jɛs, aɪ θɔɾ əz mʌtʃ fɹəm lʊkɪŋ ət ju. hu . . . ?"

Morgase frowned, looking down at her. "Yes, I thought as much from looking at you. Who . . . ?"

"ɹænd," ɪleɪn sɛd, blʌʃɪŋ, "ðoʊ ɪts nɑt waɪdli noʊn, ən aɪd ɹæðɝ ɪt steɪ ðət weɪ."

"Rand," Elayne said, blushing, "though it's not widely known, and I'd rather it stay that way."

"ɹæn ælθɹ . . ." mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd, hɝ mud dɑɹkənɪŋ. "ðæt-__"

"Rand al'Thor . . ." Morgase said, her mood darkening. "That-__"

"mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə ɡɹæsp hɝz. "hiz ə ɡʊd mæn ən aɪ lʌv hɪm. wʌt juv hɝɾ ɪz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃən əɹ bɪɾɝ ɹumɝ"

"Mother," Elayne said, raising a hand to grasp hers. "He's a good man and I love him. What you have heard is exaggeration or bitter rumor"

"bʌt hiz . . . ɪleɪn, ə mæn u kən tʃænəl, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn'"

"But he's . . . Elayne, a man who can channel, the Dragon Reborn'"

"æn stɪl ə mæn," ɪleɪn sɛd, filɪŋ ɪz nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd, soʊ wɔɹm.

"And still a man," Elayne said, feeling his knot of emotions in the back of her mind, so warm.

"dʒʌst ə mæn, fəɹ ɔl ðəɾ ɪz dɪmændəɾ ə hɪm."

"Just a man, for all that is demanded of him."

mɔɹɡeɪs dʒɹu hɝ lɪps ɪndə ə θɪn laɪn. "aɪ ʃæl wɪθhoʊl dʒʌdʒmənt. ðoʊ ɪn ə weɪ aɪ stɪl fil ðəɾ aɪ ʃʊɾə θɹoʊn ðət bɔɪ ɪn ðə pæl-eɪs dʌnʒənz ðə moʊmənt wi faʊn ɪm skʌlkɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz. aɪ dɪdn laɪk haʊ hi lʊkt ət jə ivən ðɛn, maɪn ju."

Morgase drew her lips into a thin line. "I shall withhold judgment. Though in a way I still feel that I should have thrown that boy in the Pal-ace dungeons the moment we found him skulking in the gardens. I didn't like how he looked at you even then, mind you."

ɪleɪn smaɪld, ðən dʒɛstʃɝd bæk tə ðə sits. mɔɹɡeɪs sæt, ən ðɪs taɪm ɪleɪn tʊk ðə sit dɝɛkli bɪsaɪd hɝ, stɪl klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ mʌðɝz hænz. ʃi sɛnst əmjuzmən fɹəm bɝdʒɪt, hu stʊd wɪð əɹ bæk əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ wɔl, wʌn ni bɛn soʊ ðət ðə soʊl ə hɝ but ɹɛstəɾ əɡɛns ðə wʊd pænəlɪŋ.

Elayne smiled, then gestured back to the seats. Morgase sat, and this time Elayne took the seat directly beside her, still clutching her mother's hands. She sensed amusement from Birgitte, who stood with her back against the far wall, one knee bent so that the sole of her boot rested against the wood paneling.

"wʌt?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"What?" Elayne asked.

"Nothing," Birgitte said. "It's good to see you two acting like mother and child, or at least woman and woman, rather than staring at each other like two posts."

"ɪleɪn ɪz kwin," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd stɪfli. "hɝ laɪf bɪlɔŋz tə hɝ pipəl, ən maɪ ɝaɪvəl θɹɛɾənd tə əpsɛɾ əɹ səksɛʃən."

"Elayne is Queen," Morgase said stiffly. "Her life belongs to her people, and my arrival threatened to upset her Succession."

"ɪt stɪl maɪt mʌɾi θɪŋz, mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ əpɪɹəns kəɾ oʊpən oʊld wunz."

"It still might muddy things, Mother," Elayne said. "Your appearance could open old wounds."

"aɪ wɪl əv tə əpɑlədʒaɪz," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "pɝhæps ɔfɝ ɹɛpɝeɪʃənz." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə steɪ əweɪ, dɔɾɝ. ɪt wəd bi bɛst ɪf ðoʊz u heɪɾəd mi stɪl θɔt mi dɛd. bʌt - "

"I will have to apologize," Morgase said. "Perhaps offer reparations." She hesitated. "I had intended to stay away, daughter. It would be best if those who hated me still thought me dead. But - "

"noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd kwɪkli, skwizɪŋ əɹ hænz. "ðɪs ɪz fəɹ ðə bɛst. wi sɪmpli wɪl əv tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɪt wɪð skɪl ən kɛɹ."

"No," Elayne said quickly, squeezing her hands. "This is for the best. We simply will have to approach it with skill and care."

mɔɹɡeɪs smaɪld. "ju meɪk mi pɹaʊd. jəl bi ə wʌndɝfəl kwin.

Morgase smiled. "You make me proud. You will be a wonderful queen.

ɪleɪn hæd tə fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə stɑp bimɪŋ. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn fɹi wɪð kɑmpləməns.

Elayne had to force herself to stop beaming. Her mother had never been free with compliments.
