"bʌt tɛl mi, bɪfɔɹ wi ɡoʊ fɝðɝ," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd, vɔɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ hɛzɪɾənt. "aɪ hæv hɝd ɹɪpɔɹts ðət ɡeɪbɹəl wɑz . . ."

"But tell me, before we go further," Morgase said, voice growing more hesitant. "I have heard reports that Gaebril was . . ."

"ɹɑvɪn," ɪleɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ. "ɪts tʃɹu, mʌðɝ."

"Rahvin," Elayne said, nodding. "It's true, Mother."

"aɪ heɪɾ ɪm fəɹ wʌɾ i dɪd. aɪ kən si hɪm, juzɪŋ mi, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ spaɪks θɹu ðə hɑɹts ən lɔɪəlti ʌv maɪ dɪɹəs fɹɛnz. ən jɛt ðəɹ ɪz ə pɑɹɾ ə mi ðət lɔŋz tə si hɪm, ɪɹæʃənəli."

"I hate him for what he did. I can see him, using me, driving spikes through the hearts and loyalty of my dearest friends. And yet there is a part of me that longs to see him, irrationally."

"hi juz kəmpʌlʃən ɑn ju," ɪleɪn sɛd sɔfli. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ʌðɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən. wɪl əv tə si ɪf ɛni fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ kən hil ɪt."

"He used Compulsion on you," Elayne said softly. "There is no other explanation. We will have to see if any from the White Tower can Heal it."

mɔɹɡeɪs ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, ɪts feɪnt naʊ, ən mæn-iəbəl aɪ hæv faʊn ənʌðɝ tə ɡɪv maɪ əfɛkʃən."

Morgase shook her head. "Whatever it was, it is faint now, and man-eable I have found another to give my affection."

ɪleɪn fɹaʊnd.

Elayne frowned.

"aɪ wɪl ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ əɾ ənʌðɝ pɔɪnt," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "aɪm nɑt sɝɾən aɪ ʌndɝstæn ɪt jɛt. fɝst wi mʌs dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də əbaʊt maɪ ɹɪtɝn."

"I will explain that at another point," Morgase said. "I'm not certain I understand it yet. First we must decide what to do about my return."

"ðæɾ ɪz izi," ɪleɪn sɛd. "wi sɛləbɹeɪt!"

"That is easy," Elayne said. "We celebrate!"

"jɛs, bʌt - "

"Yes, but - "

"bʌt nʌθɪŋ, mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ju hæv ɹɪtɝn tə ʌs! ðə sɪɾi, ði ɪntaɪɝ neɪʃən, wɪl sɛləbɹeɪt." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "æn æftɝ ðæt, wɪl faɪn ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt fʌŋkʃən fəɹ ju."

"But nothing, Mother," Elayne said. "You have returned to us! The city, the entire nation, will celebrate." She hesitated. "And after that, we will find an important function for you."

"sʌmθɪŋ ðət teɪks mi əweɪ fɹəm ðə kæpəɾəl, soʊ aɪ kæs noʊ ənfɔɹtʃənət ʃædoʊz."

"Something that takes me away from the capital, so I cast no unfortunate shadows."

"bʌɾ ə duɾi ðəɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, soʊ ðət jə ɑɹ nɑt θɔɾ ʌv əz hævɪŋ bɪn pʊɾ aʊt tə pæstʃɝ."

"But a duty that is important, so that you are not thought of as having been put out to pasture."

ɪleɪn ɡɹɪməst. "pɝhæps wi kən ɡɪv jə tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə wɛstɝn kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm. aɪ hæv lɪɾəl plɛʒɝ ɪn ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ʌv wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ ðɛɹ."

Elayne grimaced. "Perhaps we can give you charge of the western quarter of the realm. I have little pleasure in the reports of what is happening there."

"ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?" mɔɹɡeɪs æskt. "æn lɔɹd pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?"

"The Two Rivers?" Morgase asked. "And Lord Perrin Aybara?"

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd.

Elayne nodded.

"hi ɪz ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ wʌn, pɛɹɪn ɪz," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd θɔtfəli. "jɛs, pɝhæps aɪ kəd bi ʌv səm jus ðɛɹ. wɪv sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ən ʌndɝstændɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi."

"He is an interesting one, Perrin is," Morgase said thoughtfully. "Yes, perhaps I could be of some use there. We have something of an understanding already."

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Elayne raised an eyebrow.

"hi wɑz bɪhaɪn maɪ seɪf ɹɪtɝn tə ju," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd. "hi ɪz ən ɑnəs mæn, ən ɑnɝəbəl əz wɛl. bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ə ɹɛbəl, dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɡʊɾ ɪntɛntʃənz. jəl nɑɾ əv ən izi taɪm ʌv ɪɾ ɪf jə kʌm tə bloʊz wɪð ðət wʌn."

"He was behind my safe return to you," Morgase said. "He is an honest man, and honorable as well. But also a rebel, despite his good intentions. You will not have an easy time of it if you come to blows with that one."

"aɪd ɹæðɝ əvɔɪɾ ɪt." ʃi ɡɹɪməst. ði iziəst weɪ tə dil wɪð ɪt wəd bi tə faɪn ɪm ən ɛksəkjut hɪm, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs ʃi wɑzn gɑnə də ðæt. ivən ɪf ɹɪpɔɹts hæɾ əɹ fjumɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ɔlmoʊst wɪʃ ðət ʃi kʊd.

"I'd rather avoid it." She grimaced. The easiest way to deal with it would be to find him and execute him, but of course she wasn't going to do that. Even if reports had her fuming enough to almost wish that she could.

'wɛl, wi ʃæl bɪɡɪn wɝkɪŋ ɑn ə weɪ." mɔɹɡeɪs smaɪld. "ɪt wɪl hɛlp jə tə hɪɹ ʌv wʌt hæpən tə mi. oʊ, ən lini ɪz seɪf. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf juv wɝiɾ oʊvɝ əɹ əɹ nɑt."

'Well, we shall begin working on a way." Morgase smiled. "It will help you to hear of what happened to me. Oh, and Lini is safe. I don't know if you've worried over her or not."

tə bi ɑnəst, aɪ dɪdnt," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, filɪŋ ə spaɪk ə ʃeɪm. "ɪt simz ðət ðə kəlæps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn ɪtsɛlf kʊdn hɑɹm lini."

To be honest, I didn't," Elayne said, grimacing, feeling a spike of shame. "It seems that the collapse of Dragonmount itself couldn't harm Lini."

mɔɹɡeɪs smaɪld, ðən bɪɡæn əɹ stɔɹi. ɪleɪn lɪsənd wɪð ɑ, ən nɑɾ ə lɪɾəl ɪksaɪtmənt. hɝ mʌðɝ lɪvd. laɪt bi blɛsɪd, soʊ mɛni θɪŋz hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ ɹisənli, bʌɾ ət list wʌn hæd ɡɔn ɹaɪt.

Morgase smiled, then began her story. Elayne listened with awe, and not a little excitement. Her mother lived. Light be blessed, so many things had gone wrong recently, but at least one had gone right.

* * * ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ət naɪt wɑz pisfəl ən kwaɪət. moʊst ænəməlz wɝ æktɪv nɪɹ dʌsk ən dɔn, wən ɪt wɑz niðɝ swɛltɝɪŋ nɔɹ fɹizɪŋ.

* * * The Three-fold Land at night was peaceful and quiet. Most animals were active near dusk and dawn, when it was neither sweltering nor freezing.

eɪvinhə sæɾ ɑn ə smɔl ɹɑk aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ, lɛɡz foʊldəd bɪniθ hɝ, lʊkɪŋ daʊn əpɑn ɹɪɾiən, ɪn ðə lænz ə ðə dʒɛn il, ðə klæn ðət wɑz nɑt. wʌns ɹɪɾiən hæd bɪn ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn pɹətɛktɪv mɪsts. ðət wɑz bɪfɔɹ ɹænd hæd kʌm. hid bɹoʊkən ðə sɪɾi ɪn θɹi vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt vɛɹi dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ weɪz.

Aviendha sat on a small rock outcropping, legs folded beneath her, looking down upon Rhuidean, in the lands of the Jenn Aiel, the clan that was not. Once Rhuidean had been shrouded in protective mists. That was before Rand had come. He'd broken the city in three very important very discomforting ways.

ðə fɝst wɑz ðə sɪmpləst. ɹænd hæd teɪkən əweɪ ðə mɪst. ðə sɪɾi hæd ʃɛɾ ɪts doʊm laɪk ən ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ ənveɪlɪŋ ɪz feɪs. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ haʊ ɹænd hæd kɑz ðə tʃɹænsfɝmeɪʃən; ʃi daʊɾɪd ðəɾ i nu hɪmsɛlf. bʌɾ ɪn ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ðə sɪɾi, hi hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪt fɝɛvɝ.

The first was the simplest. Rand had taken away the mist. The city had shed its dome like an algai'd'siswai unveiling his face. She didn't know how Rand had caused the transformation; she doubted that he knew himself. But in exposing the city, he had changed it forever.

ðə sɛkənd weɪ ɹænd hæd bɹoʊkən ɹɪɾiən wɑz baɪ bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪt wɔɾɝ ə ɡɹæn leɪk leɪ bɪsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, ən fæntəm munlaɪt, fɪltɝd θɹu klaʊdz əbʌv, meɪd ðə wɔɾɝz ʃaɪn. ðə pipəl wɝ kɔlɪŋ ðə leɪk tsɑdʒɹɛlimən. tɪɹz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ðoʊ ðə leɪk ʃəd bi kɔl tɪɹz ə ði il. ɹænd ælθɹ hæd nɑt noʊn haʊ mʌtʃ peɪn i wəd kɑz ɪn wʌɾ i ɹɪvild. sətʃ wɑz ðə weɪ wɪð hɪm. hɪz ækʃənz wɝ ɔfən soʊ ɪnəsənt.

The second way Rand had broken Rhuidean was by bringing it water A grand lake lay beside the city, and phantom moonlight, filtered through clouds above, made the waters shine. The people were calling the lake Tsodrelle'Aman. Tears of the Dragon, though the lake should be called Tears of the Aiel. Rand al'Thor had not known how much pain he would cause in what he revealed. Such was the way with him. His actions were often so innocent.

ðə θɝd weɪ ɹænd hæd bɹoʊkən ðə sɪɾi wɑz ðə moʊs pɹoʊfaʊnd. eɪvinhə wɑz sloʊli kʌmɪŋ tə ʌndɝstæn ðɪs wʌn. nɑkoʊmiz wɝdz wɝid hɝ, ənnɝv hɝ. ðeɪ hæɾ əweɪkən ɪn əɹ ʃædoʊz ə mɛmɹiz, θɪŋz fɹəm pətɛnʃəl fjutʃɝz tʃæɾ eɪvinhə hæd sin ɪn ðə ɹɪŋz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ fɝs vɪzət tə ɹɪɾiən, bʌt ðəɾ əɹ maɪn kəd nɑt kwaɪt ɹikɔl, ət lis nɑt dɝɛkli.

The third way Rand had broken the city was the most profound. Aviendha was slowly coming to understand this one. Nakomi's words worried her, unnerved her. They had awakened in her shadows of memories, things from potential futures chat Aviendha had seen in the rings during her first visit to Rhuidean, but that her mind could not quite recall, at least not directly.

ʃi wɝid ðət ɹɪɾiən wəd stɑp mæɾɝɪŋ vɛɹi sun. wʌns, ðə sɪɾiz ʌltəmət pɝpəs hæd bɪn tə ʃoʊ waɪz wʌnz ən klæn tʃifs ðɛɹ pipəlz sikɹət pæst. tə pɹipɛɹ əm fəɹ ðə deɪ wən ðeɪd sɝv ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðət deɪ hæd kʌm. soʊ hu ʃəd kʌm tə ɹɪɾiən naʊ? sɛndɪŋ ði il liɾɝz θɹu ðə ɡlæs kɑləmz wəd bi ɹimaɪndɪŋ əm ə toʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪɡʌn tə mit.

She worried that Rhuidean would stop mattering very soon. Once, the city's ultimate purpose had been to show Wise Ones and clan chiefs their people's secret past. To prepare them for the day when they'd serve the Dragon. That day had come. So who should come to Rhuidean now? Sending the Aiel leaders through the glass columns would be reminding them of toh they had begun to meet.

ðɪs bɑðɝɾ eɪvinhə ɪn weɪz ðəɾ ɪtʃt bɪniθ əɹ skɪn. ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə æknɑlɪdʒ ðiz kwɛstʃənz. ʃi wɑntəd tə kəntɪnju wɪð tʃɹədɪʃən. bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ əm aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd.

This bothered Aviendha in ways that itched beneath her skin. She didn't want to acknowledge these questions. She wanted to continue with tradition. But she could not get them out of her head.

ɹænd kɑz soʊ mɛni pɹɑbləmz. stɪl, ʃi lʌv hɪm. ʃi lʌvd ɪm fəɹ ɪz ɪɡnɝəns, ɪn ə weɪ. ɪɾ əlaʊɾ ɪm tə lɝn. ən ʃi lʌvd ɪm fəɹ ðə fulɪʃ weɪ hi tʃɹaɪd tə pɹətɛk ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi pɹətɛktəd.

Rand caused so many problems. Still, she loved him. She loved him for his ignorance, in a way. It allowed him to learn. And she loved him for the foolish way he tried to protect those who did not want to be protected.

moʊst ʌv ɔl, ʃi lʌvd ɪm fəɹ ɪz dɪzaɪɝ tə bi stʃɹɔŋ. eɪvinhə hæɾ ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ. lɝn ðə spɪɹ. faɪɾ ən ɝn dʒi.. bi ðə bɛst.

Most of all, she loved him for his desire to be strong. Aviendha had always wanted to be strong. Learn the spear. Fight and earn ji.. Be the best.

ʃi kəd fil ɪm naʊ, dɪstən fɹəm hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ soʊ əlaɪk ɪn ðɪs weɪ.

She could feel him now, distant from her. They were so alike in this way.

hɝ fiɾ ætʃt fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ. ʃid ɹʌbd əm wɪð ðə sæp ʌv ə sɛɡeɪd plænt, bʌt ʃi kəd stɪl fil əm θɹɑbɪŋ. hɝ buts sæɾ ɑn ðə stoʊn bɪsaɪd hɝ, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə faɪn wʊlən stɑkɪŋz ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd ɡɪvən hɝ.

Her feet ached from running. She'd rubbed them with the sap of a segade plant, but she could still feel them throbbing. Her boots sat on the stone beside her, along with the fine woolen stockings that Elayne had given her.

ʃi wɑz taɪɝɾ ən θɝsti - ʃi wəd fæs ðɪs naɪt, kɑntəmpleɪɾɪŋ, ðən ɹifɪl əɹ wɔɾɝskɪn ət ðə leɪk bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ɹɪɾiən təmɑɹoʊ. tənaɪt, ʃi sæɾ ən θɔt, pɹipɛɹɪŋ.

She was tired and thirsty - she would fast this night, contemplating, then refill her waterskin at the lake before going into Rhuidean tomorrow. Tonight, she sat and thought, preparing.

ðə laɪvz ə ði il wɝ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ɪt wɑz stʃɹɛŋkθ tə æksɛp tʃeɪnʒ wən ɪt kəd nɑt bi əvɔɪɾəd. ɪf ə hoʊld wɑz dæmədʒ dʊɹɪŋ ə ɹeɪɾ ən jə ɹibɪlt ɪt, jə nɛvɝ meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm weɪ. jə tʊk ðə tʃæns tə fɪks ðə pɹɑbləmz - ðə dɔɹ ðət kɹikt ɪn ðə wɪnd, ði ənivən sɛkʃən ə flɔɹ. tə meɪk ɪɾ ɪɡzækli əz ɪt hæd bɪn wəd bi fulɪʃnəs.

The lives of the Aiel were changing. It was strength to accept change when it could not be avoided. If a hold was damaged during a raid and you rebuilt it, you never made it exactly the same way. You took the chance to fix the problems - the door that creaked in the wind, the uneven section of floor. To make it exactly as it had been would be foolishness.

pɝhæps tʃɹədɪʃənz - sətʃ əz kʌmɪŋ tə ɹɪɾiən, ən ivən lɪvɪŋ ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ɪtsɛlf -  wəd nid tə bi ɹiɪɡzæmən ɪvɛntʃəwəli. bʌt fəɹ naʊ, ði il kʊdn liv ðə wɛtlænz. ðəɹ wɑz ðə læs bæɾəl. ən ðən ðə sintʃæn hæd kæptʃɝd mɛni il ən meɪd waɪz wʌnz ɪndə deɪmeɪn; ðət kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd. ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ stɪl əsum ðəɾ ɔl il waɪz wʌnz u kəd tʃænəl wɝ waɪldɝz. sʌmθɪŋ wəɾ əv tə bi dʌn əbaʊt ðæt.

Perhaps traditions - such as coming to Rhuidean, and even living in the Three-fold Land itself -  would need to be reexamined eventually. But for now, the Aiel couldn't leave the wetlands. There was the Last Battle. And then the Seanchan had captured many Aiel and made Wise Ones into damane; that could not be allowed. And the White Tower still assumed that all Aiel Wise Ones who could channel were wilders. Something would have to be done about that.

ən hɝsɛlf? ðə mɔɹ ʃi θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi kʊdnt ɡoʊ bæk tə hɝ oʊld laɪf. ʃi hæd tə bi wɪð ɹænd. ɪf i sɝvaɪv ðə læs bæɾəl - ən ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə faɪt hɑɹd tə meɪk sɝɾən i dɪd - hi wəd stɪl bi ə wɛtləndɝ kɪŋ. ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ɪleɪn. eɪvinhə ən ʃi wɝ gɑnə bi sɪstɝ-waɪvz, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wəd nɛvɝ liv ændɝ. wəd ʃi ɪkspɛkt ɹænd tə steɪ wɪð hɝ?

And herself? The more she thought of it, she realized that she couldn't go back to her old life. She had to be with Rand. If he survived the Last Battle - and she intended to fight hard to make certain he did - he would still be a wetlander king. And then there was Elayne. Aviendha and she were going to be sister-wives, but Elayne would never leave Andor. Would she expect Rand to stay with her?

wəd ðət min eɪvinhə wəd nid tə əz wɛl?

Would that mean Aviendha would need to as well?

soʊ tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ, boʊθ fəɹ hɝsɛlf ən əɹ pipəl. tʃɹədɪʃənz ʃəd nɑt bi meɪnteɪn dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹədɪʃənz. stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz nɑt stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪf ɪt hæd noʊ pɝpəs əɹ dɝɛkʃən.

So troubling, both for herself and her people. Traditions should not be maintained just because they were traditions. Strength was not strength if it had no purpose or direction.

ʃi stʌɾid ɹɪɾiən, sətʃ ə ɡɹæn pleɪs ə stoʊn ən mædʒəsti. moʊst sɪɾiz dɪsɡʌstəɾ əɹ wɪð ðɛɹ kɝʌp fɪlθ, bʌt ɹɪɾiən wɑz dɪfɹənt. doʊmd ɹufs, hæf-fɪnɪʃt mɑnəlɪθs ən taʊɝz, kɛɹfəli plæn sɛkʃənz wɪð dwɛlɪŋz. ðə faʊntənz floʊd naʊ, ən ðoʊ ə lɑɹdʒ sɛkʃən stɪl bɔɹ ðə skɑɹz ʌv wən ɹænd hæd fɔt ðɛɹ. mʌtʃ ə ðət hæd bɪn klin ʌp baɪ ðə fæmliz u lɪv hɪɹ, il u hæd nɑt ɡɔn tə wɔɹ.

She studied Rhuidean, such a grand place of stone and majesty. Most cities disgusted her with their corrupt filth, but Rhuidean was different. Domed roofs, half-finished monoliths and towers, carefully planned sections with dwellings. The fountains flowed now, and though a large section still bore the scars of when Rand had fought there. Much of that had been cleaned up by the families who lived here, Aiel who had not gone to war.

ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ʃɑps. noʊ ɑɹɡjəməns ɪn stʃɹits, noʊ mɝɾɝɝz ɪn æliz. ɹɪɾiən maɪɾ əv bɪn dɪpɹaɪvd ə minɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd ɹeɪ-meɪn ə pleɪs ə pis.

There would be no shops. No arguments in streets, no murderers in alleys. Rhuidean might have been deprived of meaning, but it would re-main a place of peace.

əl ɡoʊ ɑn, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd. pæs θɹu ðə ɡlæs kɑləmz. pɝhənz əɹ wɝ-ɹaɪz wɝ tʃɹu, ən ðə pæsədʒ wɑz naʊ fɑɹ lɛs minɪŋfəl, bʌt ʃi wɑz dʒɛnjəwənli kjʊɹiəs tə si wʌt ði ʌðɝz hæd sin.

I will go on, she decided. Pass through the glass columns. Perhans her wor-ries were true, and the passage was now far less meaningful, but she was genuinely curious to see what the others had seen.

bɪsaɪdz noʊɪŋ wʌnz pæst wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ʌndɝstæn ðə fjutʃɝ.

Besides knowing ones past was important in order to understand the future.

waɪz wʌnz ən klæn tʃifs hæd bɪn vɪzəɾɪŋ ðɪs loʊkeɪʃən fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz ðeɪ ɹɪtɝnd wɪð nɑlədʒ. meɪbi ðə sɪɾi wəd ʃoʊ hɝ wʌt tə də əbaʊɾ əɹ pipəl, ən əbaʊɾ əɹ oʊn hɑɹt.

Wise Ones and clan chiefs had been visiting this location for centuries They returned with knowledge. Maybe the city would show her what to do about her people, and about her own heart.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɪks


CHAPTER 46

wɝkɪŋ lɛðɝ


Working Leather

ænʒɹəl kɛɹfəli tʊk ði oʊvəl pis ə lɛðɝ fɹəm ðə stimɪŋ wɔɾɝ; ɪt hæd dɑɹkən ən kɝld. hi muv kwɪkli, pɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp ɪn ɪz kælʌz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə lɛðɝ wɑz spɹɪŋi ən flɛksəbəl naʊ.

Androl carefully took the oval piece of leather from the steaming water; it had darkened and curled. He moved quickly, picking it up in his callused fingers. The leather was springy and flexible now.

hi kwɪkli sæt daʊn əɾ ɪz bɛntʃ, ə skwɛɹ ə sʌnlaɪt kʌmɪŋ ɪn θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt saɪd. hi ɹæp ðə lɛðɝ ɝaʊn ə θɪk wʊɾən ɹɑɾ əbaʊt tu ɪntʃəz əkɹɔs, ðən poʊk hoʊlz ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒəz.

He quickly sat down at his bench, a square of sunlight coming in through the window on his right side. He wrapped the leather around a thick wooden rod about two inches across, then poked holes around the edges.

fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi bɪɡæn stɪtʃɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ tə ənʌðɝ pis hid pɹipɛɹɾ ɝliɝ. ə ɡʊd stɪtʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ði aʊtsaɪd wəd kip ɪt fɹəm fɹeɪɪŋ. ə lɑɾ ə lɛðɝwɝkɝz wɝ kæʒəwəl əbaʊt stɪtʃɪŋ.

From there, he began stitching the leather to another piece he'd prepared earlier. A good stitching around the outside would keep it from fraying. A lot of leatherworkers were casual about stitching.

nɑɾ ænʒɹəl. ðə stɪtʃɪŋ wɑz wʌt pipəl sɔ fɝst; ɪt stʊɾ aʊt, laɪk peɪn ɑn ə wɔl.

Not Androl. The stitching was what people saw first; it stood out, like paint on a wall.

əz i wɝkt, ðə lɛðɝ dʒɹaɪɾ ən lɔst səm ʌv ɪts spɹɪŋʒənəs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl flɛksəbəl ɪnʌf.

As he worked, the leather dried and lost some of its springiness, but it was still flexible enough.

hi meɪd ðə stɪtʃɪz niɾ ən ivən. hi pʊl ðə læs fju taɪɾ ən juzd əm tə taɪ ðə lɛðɝ ɝaʊn ðə wʊɾən ɹɑd; hid kʌt ðoʊz læst wʌns ðə lɛðɝ dʒɹaɪd.

He made the stitches neat and even. He pulled the last few tight and used them to tie the leather around the wooden rod; he'd cut those last once the leather dried.

stɪtʃɪŋ dʌn, hi æɾəd səm ɔɹnəməns. ə neɪm əkɹɔs ðə tɑp, paʊndɪɾ ɪndə pleɪs juzɪŋ ɪz smɔl mælɪɾ ən lɛɾɝ-tɑpt pɪnz. ðə sɪmbəlz ə ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən keɪm nɛkst; hid meɪd ðoʊz pleɪts hɪmsɛlf, beɪst ɑn ðə pɪnz ði æʃəmən wɔɹ.

Stitching done, he added some ornaments. A name across the top, pounded into place using his small mallet and letter-topped pins. The symbols of the Sword and Dragon came next; he'd made those plates himself, based on the pins the Asha'man wore.

ət ðə bɑɾəm, juzɪŋ ɪz smɔlɝ lɛɾɝ pɪnz, hi stæmp ðə wɝdz, dɪfɛnd. ɡɑɹd. pɹətɛkt." əz ðə lɛðɝ kəntɪnjud tə dʒɹaɪ, hi ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ɪz steɪn ən ɡɔz tə kɛɹfəli kʌlɝ ðə lɛɾɝz ən ðə dɪzaɪnz fəɹ kɑntʃɹæst.

At the bottom, using his smaller letter pins, he stamped the words, Defend. Guard. Protect." As the leather continued to dry, he got out his stain and gauze to carefully color the letters and the designs for contrast.

ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃɹæŋkwɪlɪɾi tə ðɪs kaɪndə wɝk; soʊ mʌtʃ ə hɪz laɪf wɑz əbaʊt dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ðiz deɪz.

There was a tranquility to this kind of work; so much of his life was about destruction these days.

hi nu ðət hæd tə bi. hid kʌm tə ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs kəz i ʌndɝstʊd wʌt wɑz tə kʌm. stɪl, ɪt wɑz naɪs tə kɹieɪt sʌmθɪŋ.

He knew that had to be. He'd come to the Black Tower in the first place because he understood what was to come. Still, it was nice to create something.

hi lɛft ɪz kɝən pis, lɛɾɪŋ ɪt dʒɹaɪ waɪl wɝkɪŋ ɑn səm sæɾəl stʃɹæps. hi mɛʒɝd ðə stʃɹæps wɪð ðə mɑɹks ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz teɪbəl ðən ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz ʃiɹz ɪn ðə tul paʊtʃ ðət hʌŋ fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz teɪbəl - hid meɪd ðət hɪmsɛlf. hi wɑz ənɔɪd tə dɪskʌvɝ ðət ðeɪ wɝn ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪs.

He left his current piece, letting it dry while working on some saddle straps. He measured the straps with the marks on the side of his table then reached for his shears in the tool pouch that hung from the side of his table - he'd made that himself. He was annoyed to discover that they weren't in their place.

bɝn ðə deɪ wɝd ɡɑɾ aʊt ðəɾ aɪ hæd ɡʊd ʃiɹz ɪn hɪɹ, hi θɔt. dɪspaɪt teɪmz səpoʊzədli stʃɹɪkt ɹulz fəɹ ðə blæk taʊɝ, ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪstʃɹɛsɪŋ əmaʊn ə keɪɑs. lɑɹdʒ ɪnfɹækʃənz wɝ pʌnɪʃt wɪð hɑɹʃ mɛʒɝz, bʌt ðə lɪɾəl θɪŋz - laɪk wɑndɝɪŋ ɪndə ə mænz wɝkʃɑp ən "bɑɹoʊɪŋ" hɪz ʃiɹz - wɝ ɪɡnɔɹd. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪf ðə bɑɹoʊɝ wɑz wʌn ə ðə lz feɪvɹɪts.

Burn the day word got out that I had good shears in here, he thought. Despite Taim's supposedly strict rules for the Black Tower, there was a distressing amount of chaos. Large infractions were punished with harsh measures, but the little things - like wandering into a man's workshop and "borrowing" his shears - were ignored. Particularly if the borrower was one of the M'Hael's favorites.

ænʒɹəl saɪd. hɪz bɛl naɪf wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ət kjulɝz pleɪs fəɹ ʃɑɹpənɪŋ. wɛl, hi θɔt, teɪm dʌz kip tɛlɪŋ əs tə lʊk fəɹ ɪkskjusɪz tə tʃænəl . . . ænʒɹəl ɛmptid hɪmsɛlf ʌv ɪmoʊʃən, ðən siz ðə sɔɹs. ɪt hæd bɪn mʌnθs sɪns hid hæd tʃɹʌbəl duɪŋ ðət - ət fɝst, hid bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃænəl oʊnli wən i wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ə stʃɹæp ə lɛðɝ. ðə l hæd biɾən ðəɾ aʊɾ ə hɪm. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ə plɛzən pɹɑsɛs.

Androl sighed. His belt knife was waiting at Cuellar's place for sharpening. Well, he thought, Taim does keep telling us to look for excuses to channel . . . Androl emptied himself of emotion, then seized the Source. It had been months since he'd had trouble doing that - at first, he'd been able to channel only when he was holding a strap of leather. The M'Hael had beaten that out of him. It had not been a pleasant process.

seɪɾɪn flʌɾəd ɪndə hɪm, swit, paʊɝfəl, bjuɾəfəl. hi sæt fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ɪt. ðə teɪnt wɑz ɡɔn. wʌɾ ə wʌndɝ ðət wɑz. hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən bɹiðd ɪn dipli.

Saidin flooded into him, sweet, powerful, beautiful. He sat for a long moment, enjoying it. The taint was gone. What a wonder that was. He closed his eyes and breathed in deeply.

wʌt wəɾ ɪt bi laɪk tə dʒɹɔ ɪn əz mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ði ʌðɝz kʊd? ət taɪmz, hi θɝstɪd fəɹ ðæt. hi nu hi wɑz wik - wikəst ə ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ. pɝhæps soʊ wik i ʃəd nɛvɝ əv bɪn pɹəmoʊɾəd fɹəm soʊlʒɝ. lɑɡən hæd ɡɔn tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən əbaʊɾ ɪt, ən meɪd ðə pɹəmoʊʃən hæpən, əɡɛns teɪmz ɪkspɹɛs wɪʃɪz.

What would it be like to draw in as much of the One Power as the others could? At times, he thirsted for that. He knew he was weak - weakest of the Dedicated in the Black Tower. Perhaps so weak he should never have been promoted from soldier. Logain had gone to the Lord Dragon about it, and made the promotion happen, against Taim's express wishes.

ænʒɹəl oʊpən ɪz aɪz, ðən hɛld ʌp ðə stʃɹæp ən woʊv ə taɪni ɡeɪtweɪ, oʊnli ən ɪntʃ əkɹɔs. ɪt bɝst əlaɪv ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, slaɪsɪŋ ðə stʃɹæp ɪn tu. hi smaɪld, ðən lɛɾ ɪt vænɪʃ ən ɹɪpiɾɪd ðə pɹɑsɛs.

Androl opened his eyes, then held up the strap and wove a tiny gateway, only an inch across. It burst alive in front of him, slicing the strap in two. He smiled, then let it vanish and repeated the process.

səm sɛd ðət lɑɡən hæd fɔɹst ænʒɹəlz pɹəmoʊʃən oʊnli əz ə dɪɡ əɡɛns teɪmz əθɔɹəɾi. bʌt lɑɡən hæd sɛd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ænʒɹəl ɛs ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl tælənt wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz ðət hæɾ ɝn ɪm ðə taɪɾəl ə dɛɾəkeɪtəd. lɑɡən wɑz ə hɑɹd mæn, bɹoʊkən ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒəz, laɪk ən oʊl skæbɝd ðət hædn bɪn pɹɑpɝli lækɝd. bʌt ðət skæbɝd stɪl hɛld ə dɛdli sɔɹd. lɑɡən wɑz ɑnəst. ə ɡʊd mæn, bɪniθ ðə skʌf mɑɹks.

Some said that Logain had forced Androl's promotion only as a dig against Taim's authority. But Logain had said that it was Androl s incredible Talent with gateways that had earned him the title of Dedicated. Logain was a hard man, broken around the edges, like an old scabbard that hadnt been properly lacquered. But that scabbard still held a deadly sword. Logain was honest. A good man, beneath the scuff marks.

ænʒɹəl ɪvɛntʃəwəli fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðə stʃɹæps. hi wɔkt oʊvɝ ən snɪp ðə stʃɹɪŋ hoʊldɪŋ ði oʊvəl pis ə lɛðɝ ɪn pleɪs. ɪt ɹɪteɪn ɪts ʃeɪp, ən i hɛld ɪɾ ʌp tə ðə sʌnlaɪt, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə stɪtʃɪŋ. ðə lɛðɝ wɑz stɪf wɪθaʊt biɪŋ bɹɪɾəl. hi fɪɾ ɪɾ ɑntu hɪz fɔɹɑɹm. jɛs, ðə moʊldɪŋ wɑz ɡʊd.

Androl eventually finished with the straps. He walked over and snipped the string holding the oval piece of leather in place. It retained its shape, and he held it up to the sunlight, inspecting the stitching. The leather was stiff without being brittle. He fit it onto his forearm. Yes, the molding was good.

hi nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf. wʌn ə ðə tʃɹɪks tə laɪf wɑz peɪɪŋ ətɛnʃən tə ðə smɔl dɪteɪlz. foʊkəs, meɪk ðə smɔl θɪŋz ɹaɪt. ɪf itʃ stɪtʃ wɑz sɪkjʊɹ ɑn ən ɑɹmɡɑɹd, ðən ɪt wʊdn fɹeɪ əɹ snæp.

He nodded to himself. One of the tricks to life was paying attention to the small details. Focus, make the small things right. If each stitch was secure on an armguard, then it wouldn't fray or snap.

ðət kəd min ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ən ɑɹtʃɝ læstɪŋ θɹu ə bɝɑʒ əɹ hævɪŋ tə pʊɾ əweɪ hɪz baʊ.

That could mean the difference between an archer lasting through a barrage or having to put away his bow.

wʌn ɑɹtʃɝ wʊdn meɪk ə bæɾəl. bʌt ðə smɔl θɪŋz paɪld ʌp, wʌn ətɑp ənʌðɝ, əntɪl ðeɪ bɪkeɪm lɑɹdʒ θɪŋz. hi fɪnɪʃt ði ɑɹmɡɑɹd baɪ əfɪksɪŋ ə fju pɝmənən taɪz tə ɪts bæk, soʊ wʌn kəd baɪn ɪɾ ɪn pleɪs ɑn ði ɑɹm.

One archer wouldn't make a battle. But the small things piled up, one atop another, until they became large things. He finished the armguard by affixing a few permanent ties to its back, so one could bind it in place on the arm.

hi tʊk ɪz blæk koʊɾ ɔf ðə bæk ə hɪz tʃɛɹ. ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd pɪn ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ ɡlɪmɝɾ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz sʌnlaɪɾ əz i dɪɾ ʌp ðə bʌɾənz. hi ɡlænst ət hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə ɡlæsəz ɹəflɛkʃən, meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðə koʊt wɑz stʃɹeɪt. smɔl θɪŋz wɝ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. sɛkənz wɝ smɔl θɪŋz, ən ɪf jə hipt ɪnʌf ə ðoʊz ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ, ðeɪ bɪkeɪm ə mænz laɪf.

He took his black coat off the back of his chair. The silver sword pin on the high collar glimmered in the window's sunlight as he did up the buttons. He glanced at himself in the glass's reflection, making certain the coat was straight. Small things were important. Seconds were small things, and if you heaped enough of those on top of one another, they became a man's life.

hi pʊt ði ɑɹmɡɑɹɾ ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, ðən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz smɔl wɝkʃɑp ən ɛntɝd ði aʊtskɝts ə ðə blæk taʊɝz vɪlədʒ. hɪɹ, klʌstɝz ə tu-stɔɹid bɪldɪŋz wɝ ɝeɪnʒd mʌtʃ laɪk ɛni smɔl taʊn ɪn ændɝ. pikt ɹufs, θætʃt, wɪð stʃɹeɪt wʊɾən wɔlz, səm stoʊn ən bɹɪk əz wɛl. ə dʌbəl laɪn ə ðɛm ɹæn daʊn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə vɪlədʒ. lʊkɪŋ oʊnli ət ðoʊz, wʌn maɪɾ əv θɔɾ i wɑz stʃɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu nu bɹəm əɹ ɡɹeɪfəndeɪl.

He put the armguard on his arm, then pushed open the door to his small workshop and entered the outskirts of the Black Tower's village. Here, clusters of two-storied buildings were arranged much like any small town in Andor. Peaked roofs, thatched, with straight wooden walls, some stone and brick as well. A double line of them ran down the center of the village. Looking only at those, one might have thought he was strolling through New Braem or Grafendale.

ʌv kɔɹs, ðət ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts. ðeɪ wɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɹʌnɪŋ ɛɹənz fəɹ ðə l, ɡoʊɪŋ tə pɹæktəs, wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə faʊndeɪʃənz ə ðə blæk taʊɝ stʃɹʌktʃɝ ɪtsɛlf. ðɪs pleɪs wɑz stɪl ə wɝk ɪn pɹəɡɹɛs. ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz - bɛɹɪŋ niðɝ ðə sɔɹd pɪn nɔɹ ðə ɹɛd- ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən - juz ðə paʊɝ tə blæst ə lɔŋ tʃɹɔf ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd. ɪt hæd bɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ðə vɪlədʒ niɾəd ə kənæl.

Of course, that required ignoring the men in black coats. They were everywhere, running errands for the M'Hael, going to practice, working on the foundations of the Black Tower structure itself. This place was still a work in progress. A group of soldiers - bearing neither the sword pin nor the red- and-gold Dragon - used the Power to blast a long trough in the ground beside the road. It had been decided that the village needed a canal.

ænʒɹəl kəd si ðə wivz - moʊsli ɝθ - spɪnɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə soʊlʒɝz. ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ, jə dɪɾ əz mʌtʃ wɪð ðə paʊɝ əz jə kʊd. ɔlweɪz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, laɪk mɛn lɪftɪŋ stoʊnz tə bɪl ðɛɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ. laɪt, haʊ lɑɡən ən teɪm pʊʃt ðoʊz lædz.

Androl could see the weaves - mostly Earth - spinning around the soldiers. In the Black Tower, you did as much with the Power as you could. Always training, like men lifting stones to build their strength. Light, how Logain and Taim pushed those lads.

ænʒɹəl muvd aʊɾ ɑntu ðə nuli ɡɹævəld ɹoʊdweɪ. mʌtʃ ə ðət ɡɹævəl bɔɹ mɛltəɾ ɛdʒəz fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪn blæstəd. ðeɪ hæd bɹɔɾ ɪn boʊldɝz - θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz, ɑn wivz ʌv ɛɹ - ðən ʃæɾɝd əm wɪð ɪksploʊsɪv wivz. ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk ə wɔɹ zoʊn, ɹɑks ʃæɾɝɪŋ, spɹeɪ-ɪŋ tʃɪps. wɪð paʊɝ - ən tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - laɪk ðæt, ði æʃəmən wəd bi eɪbəl tə ɹədus sɪɾi wɔlz tə ɹʌbəl.

Androl moved out onto the newly graveled roadway. Much of that gravel bore melted edges from where it had been blasted. They had brought in boulders - through gateways, on weaves of Air - then shattered them with explosive weaves. It had been like a war zone, rocks shattering, spray-ing chips. With Power - and training - like that, the Asha'man would be able to reduce city walls to rubble.

ænʒɹəl kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn ɪz weɪ. ðə blæk taʊɝ wɑz ə pleɪs ə stʃɹeɪnʒ saɪts, ən mɛltəd ɡɹævəl wɑznt nɪɹli ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst ə ðɛm. niðɝ wɝ ðə soʊlʒɝz tɛɹɪŋ ʌp ɡɹaʊnd, fɑloʊɪŋ ænʒɹəl ɛs oʊn kɛɹfəl sɝveɪɪŋ. leɪtli, ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst saɪt tə hɪm wɑz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðeɪ ɹæn ən pleɪd, dʒʌmpɪŋ ɪndə ðə tʃɹɔf lɛf bɪhaɪn baɪ ðə wɝkɪŋ soʊlʒɝz, slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɪts ɝθən saɪdz, ðən skɹæmbəlɪŋ bæk ʌp.

Androl continued on his way. The Black Tower was a place of strange sights, and melted gravel wasn't nearly the strangest of them. Neither were the soldiers tearing up ground, following Androl s own careful surveying. Lately, the strangest sight to him was the children. They ran and played, jumping into the trough left behind by the working soldiers, sliding down its earthen sides, then scrambling back up.

tʃɪlʒɹən. pleɪɪŋ ɪn ðə hoʊlz kɹieɪɾəd baɪ seɪɾɪn blæsts. ðə wɝld wɑz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ænʒɹəlz oʊn ɡɹæmə - soʊ eɪntʃənt ʃid lɔst ɛvɹi tuθ ɪn əɹ maʊθ - hæd juz stɔɹiz ə mɛn tʃænəlɪŋ tə fɹaɪɾən ɪm ɪndə bɛɾ ɑn naɪts wən i tʃɹaɪd tə slɪp aʊtsaɪɾ ən kaʊn ðə stɑɹz. ðə dɑɹknəs aʊtsaɪd hædn fɹaɪɾənd hɪm, nɔɹ hæd stɔɹiz ə tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz. bʌt mɛn u kəd tʃænəl . . . ðət hæd tɛɹəfaɪd hɪm.

Children. Playing in the holes created by saidin blasts. The world was changing. Androl's own gramma - so ancient she'd lost every tooth in her mouth - had used stories of men channeling to frighten him into bed on nights when he tried to slip outside and count the stars. The darkness outside hadn't frightened him, nor had stories of Trollocs and Fades. But men who could channel . . . that had terrified him.

naʊ hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf hɪɹ, ɡɹoʊn ɪndə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, sʌɾənli əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk bʌt kəmplitli ət pis wɪð mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. hi wɔk daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, ɡɹævəl kɹʌntʃɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz buts. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən keɪm skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə dɪtʃ ən flɑkt ɝaʊn hɪm. hi aɪdli bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ə hændfʊl ə kændiz, pɝtʃəst ɑn ðə læst skaʊɾɪŋ mɪʃən.

Now he found himself here, grown into his middle years, suddenly afraid of the dark but completely at peace with men who could channel. He walked down the road, gravel crunching beneath his boots. The children came scrambling up out of the ditch and flocked around him. He idly brought out a handful of candies, purchased on the last scouting mission.

"tu itʃ," hi sɛd stɝnli əz dɝɾi hænz ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə kændiz. "ænd noʊ ʃʌvɪŋ, maɪn ju."

"Two each," he said sternly as dirty hands reached for the candies. "And no shoving, mind you."

hænz wɛn tə maʊðz, ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɡeɪv ɪm bɑb hɛdz ɪn θæŋks, kɔlɪŋ ɪm "mæstɝ ɡɛnhəld," bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪsɪŋ əweɪ. ðeɪ dɪdnt ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə tʃɹɛntʃ, bʌɾ ɪnvɛntəɾ ə nu ɡeɪm, ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf təwɔɹd ðə filz tə ði ist.

Hands went to mouths, and the children gave him bobbed heads in thanks, calling him "Master Genhald," before racing away. They didn't go back to the trench, but invented a new game, running off toward the fields to the east.

ænʒɹəl bɹʌʃt ɔf ɪz hænz, smaɪlɪŋ. tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ soʊ ədæptəbəl. bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, sɛntʃɝiz ə tʃɹədɪʃən, tɛɹɝ ən supɝstɪʃən kəd mɛlt əweɪ laɪk bʌɾɝ lɛf tu lɔŋ ɪn ðə sʌn. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡʊd ðət ðeɪd tʃoʊzən tə liv ðə tʃɹɛntʃ. ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəd bi ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl.

Androl brushed off his hands, smiling. Children were so adaptable. Before them, centuries of tradition, terror and superstition could melt away like butter left too long in the sun. But it was good that they'd chosen to leave the trench. The One Power could be unpredictable.

noʊ. ðət wɑzn ɹaɪt. seɪɾɪn wɑz vɛɹi pɹɪdɪktəbəl. ðə mɛn u wildɪɾ ɪt, haʊɛvɝ . . . wɛl, ðeɪ wɝ ə dɪfɹən stɔɹi.

No. That wasn't right. Saidin was very predictable. The men who wielded it, however . . . well, they were a different story.

ðə soʊlʒɝz hɔltəd ðɛɹ wɝk ən tɝn tə mit hɪm. hi wɑzn ə fʊl æʃəmən, ən dɪdn mɛɹəɾ ə səlut, bʌt ðeɪ ʃoʊɾ ɪm ɹɪspɛkt. tu mʌtʃ. hi wɑznt ʃʊɹ waɪ ðeɪ dɪfɝd tə hɪm. hi wɑz noʊ ɡɹeɪt mæn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli nɑt hɪɹ, ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ.

The soldiers halted their work and turned to meet him. He wasn't a full Asha'man, and didn't merit a salute, but they showed him respect. Too much. He wasn't sure why they deferred to him. He was no great man, particularly not here, in the Black Tower.

stɪl, ðeɪ nɑɾəd tə hɪm əz i pæst. moʊst ə ðiz wɝ əmʌŋ ðə mɛn u hæd bɪn ɹɪkɹuɾɪd fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. stɝɾi lædz ən mɛn, iɡɝ, ðoʊ mɛni wɝ ɑn ðə jʌŋ saɪd. hæf ə ðɛm dɪdnt nid tə ʃeɪv bʌt wʌns ə wik. ænʒɹəl wɔkt ʌp tə ðɛm, ðən ɪnspɛktɪd ðɛɹ wɝk, aɪɪŋ ðə laɪn ə stʃɹɪŋ hid taɪd tə smɔl steɪks. hi nɑɾəd ɪn æp-pɹɑvəl. "æŋɡəl ɪz ɡʊd, lædz," hi sɛd. "bʌt kip ðə saɪdz stipɝ, ɪf jə kæn."

Still, they nodded to him as he passed. Most of these were among the men who had been recruited from the Two Rivers. Sturdy lads and men, eager, though many were on the young side. Half of them didn't need to shave but once a week. Androl walked up to them, then inspected their work, eyeing the line of string he'd tied to small stakes. He nodded in ap-proval. "Angle is good, lads," he said. "But keep the sides steeper, if you can."

"jɛs, mæstɝ ɡɛnhəld," sɛd ðə wʌn liɾɪŋ ðə tim. dʒeɪm tɔɹfɪn wɑz ɪz neɪm, ə spɪnli jʌŋ mæn wɪð dʌsti bɹaʊn hɛɹ. hi stɪl hɛld i paʊɝ. ðət ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ɹɪvɝ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz soʊ ɛntaɪsɪŋ. ɹɛɹ wɑz ðə mæn u kəd ɹilis ɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə sɛns ə lɔs.

"Yes, Master Genhald," said the one leading the team. Jaim Torfinn was his name, a spindly young man with dusty brown hair. He still held he Power. That raging river of strength was so enticing. Rare was the man who could release it without a sense of loss.

ðə l ɛnkɝɪdʒd əm tə kip hoʊld ʌv ɪt, sɛd ðət hoʊldɪŋ ɪt tɔɾ əm tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. bʌɾ ænʒɹəl hæd noʊn sɪdʌktɪv sɛnseɪʃənz sʌmwʌt laɪk seɪɾɪn bɪfɔɹ - ði ɪɡzɪlɝeɪʃən ə bæɾəl, ði ɪntɑksəkeɪʃən ə ɹɛɹ dʒɹɪŋks fɹəm ði aɪlz ə ðə si foʊk, ðə hɛɾi filɪŋ ə vɪktɝi. ə mæn kəd bi swɛpt ʌp ɪn ðoʊz filɪŋz ən luz kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf, fɝɡɛɾɪŋ u hi wɑz. ən seɪɾɪn wɑz mɔɹ sɪdʌktɪv ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls hiɾ ɪkspɪɹiənst.

The M'Hael encouraged them to keep hold of it, said that holding it taught them to control it. But Androl had known seductive sensations somewhat like saidin before - the exhilaration of battle, the intoxication of rare drinks from the Isles of the Sea Folk, the heady feeling of victory. A man could be swept up in those feelings and lose control of himself, forgetting who he was. And saidin was more seductive than anything else he'd experienced.

hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ tə teɪm əbaʊɾ ɪz ɹɛzɝveɪʃənz. hi hæd noʊ bɪznəs lɛktʃɝɪŋ ðə l.

He said nothing to Taim about his reservations. He had no business lecturing the M'Hael.

"hɪɹ," ænʒɹəl sɛd, "lɛt mi ʃoʊ jə wʌɾ aɪ min baɪ stʃɹeɪt." hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ɛmptid hɪmsɛlf ə filɪŋ. hi juz ði oʊl soʊlʒɝz tʃɹɪk tə də ðət - hid bɪn tɔɾ ɪt baɪ hɪz fɝst ɪnstʃɹʌktɝ ɪn ðə sɔɹd, oʊld wʌn-ɑɹmd ɡɑɹfən, huz hɛvi ɹʊɹəl ɪliɑnɝ æksɛn hæd bɪn vɝtʃuəli ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl. ʌv kɔɹs, ænʒɹəl hɪmsɛlf hæɾ ə feɪn tæɹɑboʊ-nɝ æksɛnt, hi wɑz toʊld. ɪt hæd feɪɾəd oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz sɪns hid læs bɪn hoʊm.

"Here," Androl said, "let me show you what I mean by straight." He took a deep breath, then emptied himself of feeling. He used the old soldier's trick to do that - he'd been taught it by his first instructor in the sword, old one-armed Garfin, whose heavy rural Illianer accent had been virtually incomprehensible. Of course, Androl himself had a faint Tarabo-ner accent, he was told. It had faded over the years since he'd last been home.

wɪðɪn ðə nʌθɪŋ - ðə vɔɪd - ænʒɹəl kəd fil ðə ɹeɪdʒɪŋ fɔɹs ðət wɑz seɪɾɪn. hi ɡɹæbd ɪɾ əz ə mæn ɡɹæb ðə nɛk ʌv ə hɔɹs ɹʌnɪŋ waɪld, hoʊpɪŋ tə stɪɹ ɪn səm smɔl weɪ bʌt moʊsli dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɑn.

Within the nothing - the void - Androl could feel the raging force that was saidin. He grabbed it as a man grabbed the neck of a horse running wild, hoping to steer in some small way but mostly just trying to hold on.

seɪɾɪn wɑz wʌndɝfəl. jɛs, ɪt wɑz mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðən ɛni ɪntɑksɪkənt. ɪt meɪd ðə wɝl mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl, mɔɹ lʌʃ. hoʊldɪŋ ðət tɛɹəbəl paʊɝ, ænʒɹəl fɛlt əz ɪf hid kʌm tə laɪf, livɪŋ ðə dʒɹaɪ hʌsk ə hɪz fɔɹmɝ sɛlf bɪhaɪnd. ɪt θɹɛɾənd tə kæɹi hɪm əweɪ ɪn ɪts swɪf kɝəns.

Saidin was wonderful. Yes, it was more powerful than any intoxicant. It made the world more beautiful, more lush. Holding that terrible Power, Androl felt as if he'd come to life, leaving the dry husk of his former self behind. It threatened to carry him away in its swift currents.

hi wɝkt kwɪkli, wivɪŋ ə taɪni tʃɹɪkəl ə ɝθ - ðə bɛst i kəd mænədʒ, fəɹ ɝθ wɑz wɛɹ i wɑz wikəst - ən kɛɹfəli ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ə ðə kənæl. "ɪf jə liv tu mʌtʃ dʒʌɾɪŋ aʊt," hi ɪkspleɪn əz i wɝkt, "ðɛn ðə kənæl floʊ wɪl steɪ mʌɾi əz ɪt wɑʃɪz əweɪ ði ɝθ ɑn ðə saɪdz. ðə stʃɹeɪɾɝ ən mɔɹ fɝm ðə saɪdz, ðə bɛɾɝ. jə si?"

He worked quickly, weaving a tiny trickle of Earth - the best he could manage, for Earth was where he was weakest - and carefully shaved the sides of the canal. "If you leave too much jutting out," he explained as he worked, "then the canal flow will stay muddy as it washes away the earth on the sides. The straighter and more firm the sides, the better. You see?"

ðə soʊlʒɝz nɑɾəd. swɛt hæd biɾɪd ɑn ðɛɹ bɹaʊz, fleɪks ə dɝt stɪkɪŋ tə ðɛɹ fɔɹhɛdz ən tʃiks. bʌt ðɛɹ blæk koʊts wɝ klin, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðə slivz. jə kəd dʒʌdʒ ə mænz ɹɪspɛk fəɹ ɪz junəfɔɹm baɪ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ i juz ðə sliv tə waɪp ɪz bɹaʊ ɑn ə deɪ laɪk ðɪs. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz lædz juz hæŋkɝtʃəfs.

The soldiers nodded. Sweat had beaded on their brows, flakes of dirt sticking to their foreheads and cheeks. But their black coats were clean, particularly the sleeves. You could judge a man's respect for his uniform by whether or not he used the sleeve to wipe his brow on a day like this. The Two Rivers lads used handkerchiefs.

ðə mɔɹ sinjɝ æʃəmən, ʌv kɔɹs, ɹɛɹli swɛɾɪd əɾ ɔl. ɪt wəd teɪk ðiz lædz mɔɹ pɹæktəs tə ɡɛt ðət daʊn waɪl kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ "ɡʊd mɛn," ænʒɹəl sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp ən ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əm æn-dʒɹoʊl leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn dʒeɪmz ʃoʊldɝ. "ju lædz ɑɹ duɪŋ ə faɪn dʒɑb hɪɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɪt ɡɹoʊz mɛn ɹaɪt."

The more senior Asha'man, of course, rarely sweated at all. It would take these lads more practice to get that down while concentrating so much "Good men," Androl said, standing up and glancing over them An-drol laid a hand on Jaim's shoulder. "You lads are doing a fine job here The Two Rivers, it grows men right."

ðə lædz bimd. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hæv ðɛm, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli kəmpɛɹd tə ðə kwɑləɾi ʌv mɛn teɪm hæd bɪn ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ leɪtli. ðə lz skaʊts kleɪm ðeɪ tʊk huɛvɝ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd, jɛt waɪ wɑz ɪt ðət moʊs ðeɪ bɹɔt bæk hæd sətʃ æŋɡɹi, ənsɛɾəlɪŋ dɪspəzɪʃənz?

The lads beamed. It was good to have them, particularly compared to the quality of men Taim had been recruiting lately. The M'Hael's scouts claimed they took whoever they could find, yet why was it that most they brought back had such angry, unsettling dispositions?

"mæstɝ ɡɛnhəld?" æskt wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz.

"Master Genhald?" asked one of the soldiers.

"jɛs, tʃɹɑst?" ænʒɹəl æskt.

"Yes, Trost?" Androl asked.

"hæv jə . . . hæv jə hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ ə mæstɝ lɑɡən?"

"Have you . . . Have you heard anything of Master Logain?"

ði ʌðɝz lʊk hoʊpfəl.

The others looked hopeful.

ænʒɹəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "hi hæzən ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ɪz skaʊɾɪŋ mɪʃən. aɪm ʃʊɹ hɪl bi bæk sun."

Androl shook his head. "He hasn't returned from his scouting mission. I'm sure he'll be back soon."

ðə lædz nɑɾəd, ðoʊ hi kəd si ðət ðeɪ wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wɝi. ðeɪ hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə.

The lads nodded, though he could see that they were beginning to worry. They had a right to.

ænʒɹəl hæd bɪn wɝiɪŋ fəɹ wiks naʊ. ɛvɝ sɪns lɑɡən hæd lɛft ɪn ðə naɪt. wɛɹ hæɾ i ɡɔn? waɪ hæɾ i teɪkən dɑnɑloʊ, mɛzɝ ən wɛlɪn - θɹi ʌv ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl dɛɾəkeɪtəd lɔɪəl tə hɪm - əlɔŋ?

Androl had been worrying for weeks now. Ever since Logain had left in the night. Where had he gone? Why had he taken Donalo, Mezar and Welyn - three of the most powerful Dedicated loyal to him - along?

ən naʊ ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmpt aʊtsaɪd, səpoʊzədli sɛnt wɪð əθɔɹəɾi fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən tə bɑn æʃəmən. teɪm hæd ɡɪvən wʌn ə hɪz hæf-smaɪlz ət ðæt, ðə kaɪn ðət nɛvɝ ɹitʃt ɪz aɪz, ən toʊld əm ðə ɡɹup fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd fɝs pɪk, sɪns ðeɪd kʌm fɝst. ði ʌðɝz weɪɾəd, ɪmpeɪʃənli.

And now there were those Aes Sedai camped outside, supposedly sent with authority from the Dragon to bond Asha'man. Taim had given one of his half-smiles at that, the kind that never reached his eyes, and told them the group from the White Tower had first pick, since they'd come first. The others waited, impatiently.

"ðə l," wʌn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn sɛd, ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹk. "hi - "

"The M'Hael," one of the Two Rivers men said, expression growing dark. "He - "

"kip jəɹ hɛdz ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝz," ænʒɹəl ɪntɝʌptɪd, "æn doʊn meɪk weɪvz. nɑt jɛt. wi weɪt fəɹ lɑɡən."

"Keep your heads on your shoulders," Androl interrupted, "and don't make waves. Not yet. We wait for Logain."

ðə mɛn saɪd, bʌt nɑɾəd. dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən, ænʒɹəl ɔlmoʊs dɪdnt noʊɾəs wən ðə ʃædoʊz nɪɹbaɪ bɪɡæn kɹipɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. ʃædoʊz ə mɛn, lɛŋθənɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt. ʃædoʊz wɪðɪn ðə tʃɹɔf. ʃædoʊz ə ɹɑks ən klɛfs ɪn ði ɝθ. sloʊli, dɪviəsli, ðeɪ tɝn təwɔɹɾ ænʒɹəl. ænʒɹəl stil hɪmsɛlf, bʌt kʊdn dɪspɛl ðə pænɪk. ðɪs wʌn tɛɹɝ i kəd fil dɪspaɪt ðə vɔɪd.

The men sighed, but nodded. Distracted by the conversation, Androl almost didn't notice when the shadows nearby began creeping toward him. Shadows of men, lengthening in the sunlight. Shadows within the trough. Shadows of rocks and clefts in the earth. Slowly, deviously, they turned toward Androl. Androl steeled himself, but couldn't dispel the panic. This one terror he could feel despite the void.

ðeɪ keɪm wɛnɛvɝ i hɛl seɪɾɪn fəɹ tu lɔŋ. hi ɹilist ɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli, ən ðə ʃædoʊz ɹɪlʌktənli kɹɛp bæk tə ðɛɹ pleɪsəz.

They came whenever he held saidin for too long. He released it immediately, and the shadows reluctantly crept back to their places.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz lædz wɑtʃt hɪm, dɪskʌmfɝɾ ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. kəd ðeɪ si ðə waɪl kæs tə ænʒɹəlz aɪz? noʊbɑdi spoʊk ə ði . . . ɪɹɛɡjəlæɾɝiz ðəɾ əflɪktəd mɛn ə ðə blæk taʊɝ. ɪt dʒʌst wɑzn dʌn. laɪk wɪspɝɪŋ dɝɾi fæmli sikɹəts.

The Two Rivers lads watched him, discomfort in their faces. Could they see the wild cast to Androl's eyes? Nobody spoke of the . . . irregulateries that afflicted men of the Black Tower. It just wasn't done. Like whispering dirty family secrets.

ðə teɪnt wɑz klɛnzd. ðiz lædz wəd nɛvɝ əv tə fil ðə θɪŋz ðəɾ ænʒɹəl dɪd. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, hi ən ði ʌðɝz u hæd bɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə klɛnzɪŋ wəd bɪkʌm ɹɛɹɪɾiz. laɪt, bʌɾ i kʊdn ʌndɝ- stænd waɪ ɛniwʌn wəd lɪsən tə hɪm. wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ ən ɪnseɪn tə but?

The taint was cleansed. These lads would never have to feel the things that Androl did. Eventually, he and the others who had been in the Tower before the cleansing would become rarities. Light, but he couldn't under- stand why anyone would listen to him. Weak in the Power and insane to boot?

ən ðə wɝs pɑɹt wɑz, hi nu - dipli, daʊn tə hɪz vɛɹi sɛntɝ - ðət ðoʊz ʃædoʊz wɝ ɹil. nɑt dʒʌst səm mædnəs kənkɑktəd baɪ hɪz maɪnd. ðeɪ wɝ ɹil, ən ðeɪ wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm ɪf ðeɪ ɹitʃt hɪm.

And the worst part was, he knew - deeply, down to his very center - that those shadows were real. Not just some madness concocted by his mind. They were real, and they would destroy him if they reached him.

ðeɪ wɝ ɹil. ðeɪ hæd tə bi.

They were real. They had to be.

oʊ, laɪt, hi θɔt, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ. iðɝ ɑpʃən ɪz tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ. iðɝ aɪm ɪnseɪn əɹ ðə dɑɹknəs ɪtsɛlf wɑns tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ mi.

Oh, Light, he thought, gritting his teeth. Either option is terrifying. Either I'm insane or the darkness itself wants to destroy me.

ðət wɑz waɪ hi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ slip ət naɪts wɪθaʊt hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn fɪɹ. səmtaɪmz i kəd ɡoʊ aʊɝz hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹs wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊz. səmtaɪmz oʊnli mɪnəts. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ.

That was why he could no longer sleep at nights without huddling in fear. Sometimes he could go hours holding the Source without seeing the shadows. Sometimes only minutes. He took a deep breath.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd, sæɾəsfaɪd ðəɾ ɪz vɔɪs - ət list - saʊndəɾ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. "ju bɛst ɡɛt bæk tə wɝk. kip ðət sloʊp muvɪŋ ðə ɹaɪt dɝɛkʃən, maɪn ju. wɪl əv ə mɛs ən ə hæf tə dil wɪð ɪf ðə wɔɾɝ oʊvɝfloʊz ən flʌdz ðɪs ɛɹiə."

"All right," he said, satisfied that his voice - at least - sounded in control. "You best get back to work. Keep that slope moving the right direction, mind you. We'll have a mess and a half to deal with if the water overflows and floods this area."

əz ðeɪ oʊbeɪd, ænʒɹəl lɛf ðɛm, kʌɾɪŋ bæk θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ. nɪɹ ðə sɛntɝ stʊd ðə bæɹəks, faɪv lɑɹdʒ, θɪk-stoʊn bɪldɪŋz fəɹ ðə soʊlʒɝz, ə dʌzən smɔlɝ bɪldɪŋz fəɹ ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd. ɹaɪt naʊ, ðɪs lɪɾəl vɪlədʒ wɑz ðə blæk taʊɝ. ðət wəd tʃeɪnʒ. ə taʊɝ pɹɑpɝ wɑz biɪŋ bɪl nɪɹbaɪ, ðə faʊndeɪʃən ɔlɹɛɾi dʌɡ.

As they obeyed, Androl left them, cutting back through the village. Near the center stood the barracks, five large, thick-stoned buildings for the soldiers, a dozen smaller buildings for the Dedicated. Right now, this little village was the Black Tower. That would change. A tower proper was being built nearby, the foundation already dug.

hi kəd vɪʒwəlaɪz wʌt ðə pleɪs maɪt sʌmdeɪ lʊk laɪk. hid wʌns wɝkt wɪð ə mæstɝ ɑɹkətɛkt - wʌn ʌv ə dʌzən dɪfɹən əpɹɛntəsʃɪps hid hɛld ɪn ə laɪf ðət səmtaɪmz sim tə hæv læstəd tu lɔŋ. jɛs, hi kəd si ɪɾ ɪn ɪz maɪnz aɪ. ə dɑmənɪɹɪŋ blæk stoʊn taʊɝ, paʊɝ-bɪlt.

He could visualize what the place might someday look like. He'd once worked with a master architect - one of a dozen different apprenticeships he'd held in a life that sometimes seemed to have lasted too long. Yes, he could see it in his mind's eye. A domineering black stone tower, Power-built.

stʃɹɔŋ, stɝɾi. əɾ ɪts beɪs wəd bi blɑkɪʃ skwɛɹ stʃɹʌktʃɝz wɪð kɹɛnəleɪɾəd tɑps.

Strong, sturdy. At its base would be blockish square structures with crenelated tops.

ðɪs vɪlədʒ wəd ɡɹoʊ tə bɪkʌm ə taʊn, ðən ə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi, əz væst əz tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðə stʃɹits hæd bɪn bɪl tə əlaʊ ðə pæsɪŋ ə sɛvɹəl wæɡənz əɾ ə taɪm. nu sɛkʃənz wɝ sɝveɪɾ ən leɪd. ɪt bɪspoʊk vɪʒən ən plænɪŋ. ðə stʃɹits ðɛmsɛlvz wɪspɝɾ ə ðə blæk taʊɝz dɛstəni.

This village would grow to become a town, then a large city, as vast as Tar Valon. The streets had been built to allow the passing of several wagons at a time. New sections were surveyed and laid. It bespoke vision and planning. The streets themselves whispered of the Black Tower's destiny.

ænʒɹəl fɑloʊɾ ə wɔɹn pæθweɪ θɹu ðə skɹʌb ɡɹæs. dɪstən bumz ən snæps ɛkoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə pleɪnz laɪk ðə saʊnz ʌv ə wɪp biɪŋ kɹækt. itʃ mæn hæɾ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz fəɹ kʌmɪŋ.

Androl followed a worn pathway through the scrub grass. Distant booms and snaps echoed across the plains like the sounds of a whip being cracked. Each man had his own reasons for coming.

ɹivɛnʒ, kjʊɹiɑsəɾi, dɛspɝeɪʃən, lʌs fəɹ paʊɝ. wɪtʃ wɑz ænʒɹəlz ɹizən? ɔl fɔɹ, pɝhæps?

Revenge, curiosity, desperation, lust for power. Which was Androl's reason? All four, perhaps?

hi lɛf ðə vɪlədʒ, ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹaʊndəɾ ə laɪn ə tʃɹiz ən keɪm tə ðə pɹæktəs ɹeɪnʒ - ə smɔl kænjən bɪtwin tu hɪlz. ə laɪn ə mɛn stʊd tʃænəlɪŋ faɪɝ ən ɝθ. ðə hɪlz niɾəd tə bi lɛvəl tə meɪk læn fəɹ fɑɹmɪŋ. ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə pɹæktəs.

He left the village, and eventually rounded a line of trees and came to the practice range - a small canyon between two hills. A line of men stood channeling Fire and Earth. The hills needed to be leveled to make land for farming. An opportunity to practice.

ðiz mɛn wɝ moʊsli dɛɾəkeɪtəd. wivz spʌn ɪn ði ɛɹ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ skɪlfəl ən paʊɝfəl ðən ðoʊz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz lædz hæd juzd. ðiz wɝ stʃɹimlaɪnd, laɪk hɪsɪŋ vaɪpɝz əɹ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ æɹoʊz.

These men were mostly Dedicated. Weaves spun in the air, much more skillful and powerful than those the Two Rivers lads had used. These were streamlined, like hissing vipers or striking arrows.

ɹɑks ɪksploʊɾəd ən bɝsts ə dɝt spɹeɪɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ðə blæstɪŋ wɑz dʌn ɪn ən ʌnpɹɪdɪkt-eɪbəl pæɾɝn tə kənfjuz ən dɪsɔɹiɛn foʊz. ænʒɹəl kəɾ ɪmædʒən ə ɡɹup ə kævəlɹi θʌndɝɪŋ daʊn ðət sloʊp, oʊnli tə bi sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ɪksploʊɾɪŋ ɝθ. ə sɪŋɡəl dɛɾəkeɪtəd kəd waɪp aʊt dʌzənz ə ɹaɪɾɝz ɪn moʊməns.

Rocks exploded and bursts of dirt sprayed into the air. The blasting was done in an unpredict-able pattern to confuse and disorient foes. Androl could imagine a group of cavalry thundering down that slope, only to be surprised by exploding Earth. A single Dedicated could wipe out dozens of riders in moments.

ænʒɹəl noʊɾəd wɪð dɪsæɾɪsfækʃən ðət ðə wɝkɪŋ mɛn stʊɾ ɪn tu ɡɹups. ðə taʊɝ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə splɪɾ ən dɪvaɪd, ðoʊz lɔɪəl tə lɑɡən ʃʌn ən ɔstʃɹəsaɪzd. ɑn ðə ɹaɪt, kænlɝ, əmɝɪn ən næləm wɝkt wɪð foʊkəs ən dɛɾəkeɪʃən, dʒɔɪn baɪ dʒɑnɪθ daʊtʃɹi - ðə moʊst skɪl soʊlʒɝ əmʌŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz lædz. ɑn ðə lɛft, ə ɡɹup ə teɪmz kɹoʊniz wɝ læfɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ðɛɹ wivz wɝ mɔɹ waɪld, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪstʃɹʌktɪv. koʊɾɝən laʊnʒd ət ðə bæk, linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə lifi hɑɹdɡəm tʃɹi ən oʊvɝsiɪŋ ðə wɝk.

Androl noted with dissatisfaction that the working men stood in two groups. The Tower was beginning to split and divide, those loyal to Logain shunned and ostracized. On the right, Canler, Emarin and Nalaam worked with focus and dedication, joined by Jonneth Dowtry - the most skilled soldier among the Two Rivers lads. On the left, a group of Taim's cronies were laughing among themselves. Their weaves were more wild, but also much more destructive. Coteren lounged at the back, leaning against a leafy hardgum tree and overseeing the work.

ðə wɝkɝz tʊk ə bɹeɪk ən kɔl fəɹ ə vɪlədʒ bɔɪ tə bɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ænʒɹəl wɔkt ʌp, ən ɑɹlən næləm sɔ hɪm fɝst, weɪvɪŋ wɪð ə bɹɔd smaɪl. ðə dəmɑni mæn wɔɹ ə θɪn mʌstæʃ. hi wɑz dʒʌst ʃaɪ ʌv ɪz θɝɾiəθ jɪɹ, ðoʊ hi səmtaɪmz æktəd mʌtʃ jʌŋɡɝ. ænʒɹəl wɑz stɪl smɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə taɪm næləm hæd pʊt tʃɹi sæp ɪn ɪz buts.

The workers took a break and called for a village boy to bring water. Androl walked up, and Arlen Nalaam saw him first, waving with a broad smile. The Domani man wore a thin mustache. He was just shy of his thirtieth year, though he sometimes acted much younger. Androl was still smarting from the time Nalaam had put tree sap in his boots.

"ænʒɹəl!" næləm kɔld. "kʌm tɛl ðiz ʌnkʌltʃɝd laʊts wʌɾ ə ɹitæʃən dɑzɝ ɪz!"

"Androl!" Nalaam called. "Come tell these uncultured louts what a Retashen Dazer is!"

"eɪ ɹitæʃən dɑzɝ?" ænʒɹəl sɛd. "ɪts ə dʒɹɪŋk. mɪks ə miɾ ən uz mɪlk. faʊl stʌf"

"A Retashen Dazer?" Androl said. "It's a drink. Mix of mead and ewe's milk. Foul stuff"

næləm lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝz pɹaʊdli. hi hæd noʊ pɪnz ɑn ɪz koʊt. hi wɑz oʊnli ə soʊlʒɝ, bʌɾ i ʃʊɾə bɪn ədvæns baɪ naʊ.

Nalaam looked at the others proudly. He had no pins on his coat. He was only a soldier, but he should have been advanced by now.

"ju bɹæɡɪŋ əbaʊt jəɹ tʃɹævəlz əɡɛn, næləm?" ænʒɹəl æskt, ənleɪsɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ ɑɹmɡɑɹd.

"You bragging about your travels again, Nalaam?" Androl asked, unlacing the leather armguard.

"wi dəmɑni ɡɛɾ ɝaʊnd," næləm sɛd. "ju noʊ, ðə kaɪndə wɝk maɪ fɑðɝ dʌz, spaɪɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɹaʊn. . . ."

"We Domani get around," Nalaam said. "You know, the kind of work my father does, spying for the Crown. . . ."

"læst wik jə sɛd jəɹ fɑðɝ wɑz ə mɝtʃənt," kænlɝ sɛd. ðə stɝɾi mæn wɑz ði oʊldəst ə ðə ɡɹup, hɪz hɛɹ ɡɹeɪɪŋ, hɪz skwɛɹ feɪs wɔɹn fɹəm mɛni jɪɹz ɪn ðə sʌn.

"Last week you said your father was a merchant," Canler said. The sturdy man was the oldest of the group, his hair graying, his square face worn from many years in the sun.

"hi ɪz," næləm sɛd. "ðæts ɪz fɹʌn fəɹ biɪŋ ə spaɪ!"

"He is," Nalaam said. "That's his front for being a spy!"

"ɑɹənt wɪmən ðə mɝtʃəns ɪn ɑɹæd dumən?" dʒɑnɪθ æskt, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. hi wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ, kwaɪət mæn wɪð ə ɹaʊn feɪs. hɪz ɪntaɪɝ fæmli-hɪz sɪblɪŋz, hɪz pɛɹəns, ən ɪz ɡɹændfɑðɝ bjul - hæd ɹiloʊkeɪɾɪd tə ðə vɪlədʒ ɹæðɝ ðən lɛɾɪŋ ɪm kʌm əloʊn.

"Aren't women the merchants in Arad Doman?" Jonneth asked, rubbing his chin. He was a large, quiet man with a round face. His entire family-his siblings, his parents, and his grandfather Buel - had relocated to the village rather than letting him come alone.

"wɛl, ðəɹ ðə bɛst," næləm sɛd, "æn maɪ mʌðɝ ɪz noʊ ɪksɛpʃən. wi mɛn noʊ ə θɪŋ əɹ tu, ðoʊ. bɪsaɪdz, sɪns maɪ mʌðɝ wɑz bɪzi ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ðə tuætɑn, maɪ fɑðɝ hæd tə teɪk oʊvɝ ðə bɪznəs."

"Well, they're the best," Nalaam said, "and my mother is no exception. We men know a thing or two, though. Besides, since my mother was busy infiltrating the Tuatha'an, my father had to take over the business."

"oʊ, naʊ ðæts dʒʌst ɹɪdɪkjələs," kænlɝ sɛd wɪð ə skaʊl. "hu wəɾ ɛvɝ wɑnə ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪɾ ə bʌntʃ ə tɪŋkɝz?"

"Oh, now that's just ridiculous," Canler said with a scowl. "Who would ever want to infiltrate a bunch of Tinkers?"

"tə lɝn ðɛɹ sikɹət ɹɛsəpiz," næləm sɛd. "ɪts sɛd ðəɾ ə tɪŋkɝ kən kʊk ə pɑɾ ə stu soʊ faɪn ðəɾ ɪɾəl meɪk jə liv haʊs ən hoʊm tə tʃɹævəl wɪð ðɛm. ɪts tʃɹu, aɪv teɪstəɾ ɪt maɪsɛlf, ən aɪ hæd tə bi taɪɾ ɪn ə ʃɛd fəɹ θɹi deɪz bɪfɔɹ ði ɪfɛkt wɔɹ ɔf."

"To learn their secret recipes," Nalaam said. "It's said that a Tinker can cook a pot of stew so fine that it will make you leave house and home to travel with them. It's true, I've tasted it myself, and I had to be tied in a shed for three days before the effect wore off."

kænlɝ snɪft. haʊɛvɝ, æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðə fɑɹmɝ æɾəd, "soʊ . . . dɪd ʃi faɪn ðə ɹɛsəpi əɹ nɑt?"

Canler sniffed. However, after a moment, the farmer added, "So . . . did she find the recipe or not?"

næləm lɔntʃt ɪndə ənʌðɝ stɔɹi, kænlɝ ən dʒɑnɪθ lɪsnɪŋ ɪntɛnli. əmɝɪn stʊd tə ðə saɪd, lʊkɪŋ ɑn wɪð əmjuzmənt - hi wɑz ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝ ɪn ðə ɡɹup, bɛɹɪŋ noʊ pɪnz. hi wɑz ən oʊldɝ mæn, wɪð θɪn hɛɹ ən ɹɪŋkəlz əɾ ɪz aɪz. hɪz ʃɔɹt waɪt bɪɹd wɑz tʃɹɪm tə ə pɔɪnt.

Nalaam launched into another story, Canler and Jonneth listening intently. Emarin stood to the side, looking on with amusement - he was the other soldier in the group, bearing no pins. He was an older man, with thin hair and wrinkles at his eyes. His short white beard was trimmed to a point.

ðə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt mæn wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ən ɪnɪɡmə; hiɾ ɝaɪvd wɪð lɑɡən wʌn deɪ, ən hæd sɛd nʌθɪŋ ə hɪz pæst. hi hæɾ ə pɔɪz bɛɹɪŋ ən ə dɛləkət weɪ ʌv spikɪŋ. hi wɑz ə noʊbəlmən, ðət wɑz sɝɾən. bʌɾ ənlaɪk moʊst ʌðɝ noʊbəlmən ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ, əmɝɪn meɪd noʊ ətɛmpt əɾ əsɝɾɪŋ ɪz pɹəzumd əθɔɹəɾi. mɛni noʊbəlmən tʊk wiks tə lɝn ðət wʌns jə dʒɔɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ, jəɹ aʊtsaɪd ɹæŋk wɑz minɪŋləs. ðət meɪɾ əm sʌlən ən snæpɪʃ, bʌɾ əmɝɪn hæd teɪkən tə laɪf ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪmiɾiətli.

The distinguished man was something of an enigma; he'd arrived with Logain one day, and had said nothing of his past. He had a poised bearing and a delicate way of speaking. He was a nobleman, that was certain. But unlike most other noblemen in the Black Tower, Emarin made no attempt at asserting his presumed authority. Many noblemen took weeks to learn that once you joined the Black Tower, your outside rank was meaningless. That made them sullen and snappish, but Emarin had taken to life in the Tower immediately.

ɪt tʊk ə noʊbəlmən wɪð tʃɹu dɪɡnəɾi tə fɑloʊ ði ɔɹɾɝz ʌv ə kɑmənɝ hæf ɪz eɪdʒ wɪθaʊt kəmpleɪnt. əmɝɪn tʊk ə sɪp ʌv wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə sɝvɪŋ bɔɪ, θæŋkɪŋ ðə læd, ðən stɛpt ʌp tə ænʒɹəl. hi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd næləm, hu wɑz stɪl tɔkɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝz. "ðæt wʌn əz ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ə ɡlimən."

It took a nobleman with true dignity to follow the orders of a commoner half his age without complaint. Emarin took a sip of water from the serving boy, thanking the lad, then stepped up to Androl. He nodded toward Nalaam, who was still talking to the others. "That one has the heart of a gleeman."

ænʒɹəl ɡɹʌntɪd. "meɪbi hi kən juz ɪt tə ɝn səm ɛkstʃɹə kɔɪn. hi stɪl oʊz mi ə nu pɛɹ ə sɑks."

Androl grunted. "Maybe he can use it to earn some extra coin. He still owes me a new pair of socks."

"æn ju, maɪ fɹɛnd, hæv ðə soʊl ʌv ə skɹaɪb!" əmɝɪn læft. "ju nɛvɝ fɝɡɛɾ ə θɪŋ, də ju?"

"And you, my friend, have the soul of a scribe!" Emarin laughed. "You never forget a thing, do you?"

ænʒɹəl ʃɹʌɡd.

Androl shrugged.

"haʊ dɪd jə noʊ wʌɾ ə ɹitæʃən dɑzɝ wɑz? aɪ kənsɪɾɝ maɪsɛlf kwaɪɾ ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd ɪn ðiz mæɾɝz, jɛɾ aɪd hɝd nɑɾ ə wɝɾ ʌv ɪt."

"How did you know what a Retashen Dazer was? I consider myself quite educated in these matters, yet I'd heard not a word of it."

"aɪ hæd wʌn wʌns," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "dʒɹæŋk ɪɾ ɑn ə bɛt."

"I had one once," Androl said. "Drank it on a bet."

"jɛs, bʌt wɛɹ?"

"Yes, but where?"

"ɹitæʃ, ʌv kɔɹs."

"Retash, of course."

"bʌt ðæts liɡz ɔf ʃɔɹ, ɪn ə klʌstɝ ʌv aɪlənz nɑɾ ivən ðə si foʊk ɔfən vɪzət!"

"But that's leagues off shore, in a cluster of islands not even the Sea Folk often visit!"

ænʒɹəl ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ət teɪmz lækiz. ə vɪlədʒ bɔɪ hæd bɹɔɾ əm ə bæskəɾ ə fud fɹəm teɪm, ðoʊ ði ə kleɪm nɑt tə pleɪ feɪvɹɪts. ɪf ænʒɹəl æskt, hid faɪn ðəɾ ə bɔɪ wɑz sʌp-poʊz tə hæv bɪn sɛnt wɪð fud fəɹ ði ʌðɝz, tu. bʌt ðət læd wʊɾə bɪkʌm lɔst, əɹ hæd fɝɡɑɾən, əɹ meɪd səm ʌðɝ ɪnəsən mɪsteɪk. teɪm wəɾ əv sʌmwʌn wɪpt, ən nʌθɪŋ wəd tʃeɪnʒ.

Androl shrugged again. He glanced over at Taim's lackeys. A village boy had brought them a basket of food from Taim, though the M'HaeI claimed not to play favorites. If Androl asked, he'd find that a boy was sup-posed to have been sent with food for the others, too. But that lad would have become lost, or had forgotten, or made some other innocent mistake. Taim would have someone whipped, and nothing would change.

"ðɪs dɪvɪʒən ɪz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ, maɪ fɹɛnd," əmɝɪn sɛd sɔfli. "haʊ kən wi faɪt fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪf wi kænɑt meɪk pis əmʌŋ aʊɝsɛlvz?"

"This division is troubling, my friend," Emarin said softly. "How can we fight for the Lord Dragon if we cannot make peace among ourselves?"

ænʒɹəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

Androl shook his head.

əmɝɪn kəntɪnjud. "ðeɪ seɪ ðət noʊ mæn feɪvɝɾ ə lɑɡən əz hæd ðə dʒɹæɡən pɪn ɪn wiks.

Emarin continued. "They say that no man favored of Logain has had the Dragon pin in weeks.

ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni, laɪk næləm ðɛɹ, hu ʃʊɾə hæd ðə sɔɹd pɪn lɔŋ əɡoʊ - bʌɾ ɑɹ dɪnaɪd ɹɪpiɾɪdli baɪ ðə l. eɪ haʊs huz mɛmbɝz skwɑbəl fəɹ əθɔɹəɾi wɪl nɛvɝ pɹizɛn ə θɹɛt tə ʌðɝ haʊsəz."

There are many, like Nalaam there, who should have had the sword pin long ago - but are denied repeatedly by the M'Hael. A House whose members squabble for authority will never present a threat to other Houses."

"waɪz wɝdz," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "bʌt wʌt ʃəd wi du? wʌt kən wi du? teɪm ɪz l, ən lɑɡən hæzən ɹɪtɝn jɛt."

"Wise words," Androl said. "But what should we do? What can we do? Taim is M'Hael, and Logain hasn't returned yet."

"pɝhæps wi kəd sɛn sʌmwʌn fəɹ hɪm," əmɝɪn sɛd. "ɔɹ meɪbi jə kəd kɑm ði ʌðɝz. aɪ fɪɹ ðət səm ə ðɛm ɑɹ nɪɹ tə snæpɪŋ, ən ɪf ə faɪt bɹeɪks aʊt, aɪ hæv lɪɾəl daʊɾ u wəd si ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ə teɪmz pʌnɪʃməns."

"Perhaps we could send someone for him," Emarin said. "Or maybe you could calm the others. I fear that some of them are near to snapping, and if a fight breaks out, I have little doubt who would see the rough side of Taim's punishments."

ænʒɹəl fɹaʊnd. "tʃɹu. bʌt waɪ mi? jəɹ fɑɹ bɛɾɝ wɪð wɝdz ðən aɪ æm, əmɝɪn."

Androl frowned. "True. But why me? You're far better with words than I am, Emarin."

əmɝɪn tʃʌkəld. "jɛs, bʌt lɑɡən tʃɹʌsts ju, ænʒɹəl. ði ʌðɝ mɛn lʊk tə ju."

Emarin chuckled. "Yes, but Logain trusts you, Androl. The other men look to you."

ðeɪ ʃʊdnt, ænʒɹəl θɔt. "aɪl si wʌɾ aɪ kən θɪŋk ʌv." næləm wɑz waɪndɪŋ ʌp fəɹ ənʌðɝ stɔɹi, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd bɪɡɪn, ænʒɹəl dʒɛstʃɝd tə dʒɑnɪθ, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ði ɑɹmɡɑɹd. "aɪ sɔ jəɹ oʊld wʌn hæd kɹækt. tʃɹaɪ ðɪs."

They shouldn't, Androl thought. "I'll see what I can think of." Nalaam was winding up for another story, but before he could begin, Androl gestured to Jonneth, holding up the armguard. "I saw your old one had cracked. Try this."

dʒɑnɪθ ɛs feɪs bɹaɪɾənd əz i tʊk ði ɑɹmɡɑɹd. "jɔɹ əmeɪzɪŋ, ænʒɹəl! aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk ɛniwʌn hæd noʊɾəst. ɪts ə sɪli θɪŋ, aɪ noʊ, bʌt. . ." hɪz smaɪl bɹɔɾənd ən i hɝid tə ə nɪɹbaɪ tʃɹi, bɪsaɪd wɪtʃ sæt səm ə ðə mɛnz ɪkwɪpmənt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dʒɑnɪθs baʊ. ðiz tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn laɪk tə hæv əm hændi.

Jonneth s face brightened as he took the armguard. "You're amazing, Androl! I didn't think anyone had noticed. It's a silly thing, I know, but. . ." His smile broadened and he hurried to a nearby tree, beside which sat some of the men's equipment, including Jonneth's bow. These Two Rivers men liked to have them handy.

dʒɑnɪθ ɹɪtɝnd, stʃɹɪŋɪŋ ðə baʊ. hi pʊɾ ɑn ði ɑɹmɡɑɹd. "fɪts laɪk ə dʒɹim!" hi sɛd, ən ænʒɹəl fɛl hɪmsɛlf smaɪlɪŋ. smɔl θɪŋz. ðeɪ kəd min soʊ mʌtʃ.

Jonneth returned, stringing the bow. He put on the armguard. "Fits like a dream!" he said, and Androl felt himself smiling. Small things. They could mean so much.

dʒɑnɪθ tʊk eɪm ən lɔntʃt ən æɹoʊ, ðə ʃæf stʃɹikɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹ, bɑstʃɹɪŋ snæpɪŋ əɡɛns ði ɑɹmɡɑɹd. ði æɹoʊ sɔɹd fɑɹ, stʃɹɪk- ɪŋ ə tʃɹi ɑn ə hɪl bɛɾɝ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ.

Jonneth took aim and launched an arrow, the shaft streaking into the air, bowstring snapping against the armguard. The arrow soared far, strik- ing a tree on a hill better than two hundred paces away.

kænlɝ wɪsəld. "eɪn ɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðoʊz baʊz ə jʊɹz, dʒɑnɪθ. nɛvɝ ɪn maɪ laɪf."

Canler whistled. "Ain't ever seen anything like those bows of yours, Jonneth. Never in my life."

ðeɪ wɝ fɛloʊ ændɔɹənz, ðoʊ kænlɝ hæd kʌm fɹəm ə taʊn mʌtʃ kloʊsɝ tə keɪɛmlɪn.

They were fellow Andorans, though Canler had come from a town much closer to Caemlyn.

dʒɑnɪθ lʊkt əɾ ɪz ʃɑt kɹɪɾɪkəli, ðən dʒɹu əɡɛn - flɛtʃɪŋ tə tʃik - ən lust. ðə ʃæft fɛl tʃɹu ən hɪt ðə vɛɹi seɪm tʃɹi. ænʒɹəl wəd ɡɛs ðət ðə ʃæfs wɝ lɛs ðən tu hændspænz əpɑɹt.

Jonneth looked at his shot critically, then drew again - fletching to cheek - and loosed. The shaft fell true and hit the very same tree. Androl would guess that the shafts were less than two handspans apart.

kænlɝ wɪsəld əɡɛn.

Canler whistled again.

"maɪ fɑðɝ tʃɹeɪn ɑn wʌn ə ðoʊz," næləm noʊɾəd. "lɝn ði ɑɹt fɹəm ə tu ɹɪvɝz mæn hum i ɹɛskjud fɹəm dʒɹaʊnɪŋ ɪn ɪljən. hæz ðə bɑstʃɹɪŋ əz ə mɪmɛntoʊ."

"My father trained on one of those," Nalaam noted. "Learned the art from a Two Rivers man whom he rescued from drowning in Illian. Has the bowstring as a memento."

kænlɝ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌɾ i sim teɪkən wɪð ðə teɪl ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ænʒɹəl dʒʌs tʃʌkəld, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "maɪn ɪf aɪ hæv ə ɡoʊ, dʒɑnɪθ? ɪm ə pɹɪɾi dɛd ʃɑt wɪð ə tɛɹən baʊ, ən ðəɹ ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ ðən moʊst."

Canler raised an eyebrow, but he seemed taken with the tale at the same time. Androl just chuckled, shaking his head. "Mind if I have a go, Jonneth? I'm a pretty dead shot with a Tairen bow, and they're a little longer than most."

"ʃʊɹli," ðə læŋki mæn sɛd, ənstʃɹæpɪŋ ði ɑɹmɡɑɹɾ ən hændɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə baʊ.

"Surely," the lanky man said, unstrapping the armguard and handing over the bow.

ænʒɹəl dɑn ði ɑɹmɡɑɹɾ ən lɪftəd ðə baʊ. ɪt wɑz ə blæk ju, ən ðəɹ wɑzn əz mʌtʃ spɹɪŋ tə ðə stʃɹɪŋ əz i wɑz juz tə. dʒɑnɪθ hændəɾ ɪm ən æɹoʊ ən ænʒɹəl mɪmɪk ðə mænz pʊl, dʒɹɔɪŋ tə hɪz tʃik.

Androl donned the armguard and lifted the bow. It was of black yew, and there wasn't as much spring to the string as he was used to. Jonneth handed him an arrow and Androl mimicked the man's pull, drawing to his cheek.

"laɪt!" hi sɛɾ ət ðə weɪɾ ə ðə pʊl. "ðoʊz ɑɹmz ə jʊɹz ɑɹ dɪsɛptɪvli smɔl, dʒɑnɪθ.

"Light!" he said at the weight of the pull. "Those arms of yours are deceptively small, Jonneth.

haʊ dʒju mænədʒ tə eɪm? aɪ kən bɛɹli kip ɪt stɛɾi!"

How do you manage to aim? I can barely keep it steady!"

dʒɑnɪθ læft əz ænʒɹəlz ɑɹmz tʃɹɛmbəld, ən i faɪnəli lust, əneɪbəl tə kip ðə baʊ dʒɹɔn fəɹ ə bɹɛθ lɔŋɡɝ. ði æɹoʊ hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊn fɑɹ ɔf tɑɹɡət. hi hændəd ðə baʊ tə dʒɑnɪθ.

Jonneth laughed as Androl's arms trembled, and he finally loosed, unable to keep the bow drawn for a breath longer. The arrow hit the ground far off target. He handed the bow to Jonneth.

"ðæt wɑz fɛɹli ɡʊd, ænʒɹəl," dʒɑnɪθ sɛd. "ə lɑɾ ə mɛn kæn ivən ɡɛt ðə stʃɹɪŋ bæk. ɡɪmi tɛn jɪɹz, ən aɪ kəɾ əv jə ʃuɾɪŋ laɪk wʌn bɔɹn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz!"

"That was fairly good, Androl," Jonneth said. "A lot of men can't even get the string back. Give me ten years, and I could have you shooting like one born in the Two Rivers!"

"aɪl stɪk tə ʃɔɹtbaʊz fəɹ naʊ," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "jud nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə ʃuɾ ə mɑnstɝ laɪk ðət fɹəm hɔɹsbæk."

"I'll stick to shortbows for now," Androl said. "You'd never be able to shoot a monster like that from horseback."

"aɪ wʊdnt nid tə!" dʒɑnɪθ sɛd.

"I wouldn't need to!" Jonneth said.

"wʌɾ ɪf jə wɝ biɪŋ tʃeɪst?"

"What if you were being chased?"

"ɪf ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ ðən faɪv ə ðɛm," dʒɑnɪθ sɛd, "aɪd teɪk əm ɔl daʊn wɪð ðɪs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɡɑt tə mi. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ðən faɪv, ðən wʌɾ æm aɪ duɪŋ ʃuɾɪŋ ət ðɛm? aɪ ʃəd bi ɹʌnɪŋ laɪk ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf wɑz æftɝ mi."

"If there were fewer than five of them," Jonneth said, "I'd take them all down with this before they got to me. If there were more than five, then what am I doing shooting at them? I should be running like the Dark One himself was after me."

ði ʌðɝ mɛn tʃʌkəld, ðoʊ ænʒɹəl kɑɾ əmɝɪn aɪɪŋ hɪm.

The other men chuckled, though Androl caught Emarin eyeing him.

pɹɑbli wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ænʒɹəl nu tə ʃuɾ ə baʊ fɹəm hɔɹsbæk i wɑz ə kin wʌn, ðət noʊbəlmən. ænʒɹəl wəɾ əv tə wɑtʃ hɪmsɛlf.

Probably wondering how Androl knew to shoot a bow from horseback He was a keen one, that nobleman. Androl would have to watch himself.

"ænd wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" ə vɔɪs æskt. "ju də bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn tə ʃuɾ ə baʊ, peɪdʒbɔɪ? ɪz ðɪs soʊ jə kən æktʃəli  dɪfɛn jɝsɛlf?"

"And what is this?" a voice asked. "You do be trying to learn to shoot a bow, pageboy? Is this so you can actually defend yourself?"

ænʒɹəl ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, tɝnɪŋ əz koʊɾɝən sɔntɝɾ ʌp. hi wɑz ə bʌlki mæn, hɪz blæk, ɔɪli hɛɹ kɛp lɔŋ ən lus. ɪt hʌŋ ɝaʊn ə blʌn feɪs wɪð pʌdʒi tʃiks. hɪz aɪz wɝ foʊkəst, deɪnʒɝəs. hi smaɪld. ðə smaɪl ʌv ə kæt ðət hæd faʊn ə ɹoʊɾənt tə pleɪ wɪð.

Androl gritted his teeth, turning as Coteren sauntered up. He was a bulky man, his black, oily hair kept long and loose. It hung around a blunt face with pudgy cheeks. His eyes were focused, dangerous. He smiled. The smile of a cat that had found a rodent to play with.

ænʒɹəl kwaɪətli əndɪd ði ɑɹmɡɑɹd, hændɪŋ ɪt tə dʒɑnɪθ. koʊɾɝən wɑz fʊl æʃəmən, ə pɝsənəl fɹɛn ə ðə l. hi aʊtʃɹæŋkt ɛvɹiwʌn hɪɹ baɪ ə lɔŋ stʃɹaɪd.

Androl quietly undid the armguard, handing it to Jonneth. Coteren was full Asha'man, a personal friend of the M'Hael. He outranked everyone here by a long stride.

"ðə l wɪl hɪɹ ə ðɪs," koʊɾɝən sɛd. "ju də bi ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ jəɹ lɛsənz. juv noʊ nid fəɹ æɹoʊz əɹ baʊz - nɑt wən jə kən kɪl wɪð ðə paʊɝ!"

"The M'Hael will hear of this," Coteren said. "You do be ignoring your lessons. You have no need for arrows or bows - not when you can kill with the Power!"

"wi ɑɹən ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ," næləm sɛd stʌbɝnli.

"We aren't ignoring anything," Nalaam said stubbornly.

"kwaɪət, læd," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "maɪn jəɹ tʌŋ."

"Quiet, lad," Androl said. "Mind your tongue."

koʊɾɝən læft. "lɪsən tə ðə peɪdʒbɔɪ, jə lɑt. ðə l wɪl hɪɹ ə jəɹ ɪmpuɾəns ɔlsoʊ."

Coteren laughed. "Listen to the pageboy, you lot. The M'Hael will hear of your impudence also."

hi foʊkəst ɑn ænʒɹəl. "siz ðə sɔɹs."

He focused on Androl. "Seize the Source."

ænʒɹəl əblaɪdʒd ɹɪlʌktənli. ðə switnəs ə seɪɾɪn floʊɾ ɪndə hɪm, ən i ɡlæns nɝvəsli tə ðə saɪd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə ðə ʃædoʊz.

Androl obliged reluctantly. The sweetness of saidin flowed into him, and he glanced nervously to the side. There was no sign of the shadows.

"soʊ pəθɛɾɪk," koʊɾɝən sɛd. "dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðət stoʊn oʊvɝ ðɛɹ."

"So pathetic," Coteren said. "Destroy that stone over there."

ɪt wɑz fɑɹ tu lɑɹdʒ fəɹ hɪm. bʌt hid dɛlt wɪð bʊliz bɪfɔɹ, ən koʊɾɝən wɑz ə bʊli ʌv ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs taɪp - wʌn wɪð paʊɝ ən əθɔɹəɾi. ðə bɛs θɪŋ tə də wɑz tə maɪnd.

It was far too large for him. But he'd dealt with bullies before, and Coteren was a bully of the most dangerous type - one with power and authority. The best thing to do was to mind.

ɪmbɛɹəsmənt wɑz ə smɔl pʌnɪʃmənt. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ fju bʊliz sim tə ʌndɝstænd.

Embarrassment was a small punishment. That was something few bullies seemed to understand.

ænʒɹəl woʊv ðə ɹɛkwəzət wiv ə faɪɝ ən ɝθ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət ðə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn. ðə θɪn wiv hɛld ɔlmoʊst ɔl ə ðə paʊɝ i kəd mænədʒ, bʌɾ ɪɾ oʊnli fleɪkt ə fju tʃɪps ɔf ðə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn.

Androl wove the requisite weave of Fire and Earth, striking at the large stone. The thin weave held almost all of the Power he could manage, but it only flaked a few chips off the large stone.

koʊɾɝən læf hɑɹɾəli, əz dɪd ðə ɡɹup ə dɛɾəkeɪtəd iɾɪŋ bɪniθ ðə nɪɹbaɪ tʃɹi. "blʌɾi æʃəz, bʌt jəɹ jusləs!" koʊɾɝən sɛd. "fɝɡɛt wʌɾ aɪ sɛɾ ɝliɝ, peɪdʒbɔɪ! jə nid ðət baʊ!"

Coteren laughed heartily, as did the group of Dedicated eating beneath the nearby tree. "Bloody ashes, but you're useless!" Coteren said. "Forget what I said earlier, pageboy! You need that bow!"

ænʒɹəl ɹilis ðə wʌn paʊɝ. koʊɾɝən hæd hæɾ ɪz læf; hi wəd bi sæɾəsfaɪd. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ænʒɹəl fɛl mɛn siz ðə sɔɹs bɪhaɪn hɪm. dʒɑnɪθ, kænlɝ ən næləm stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ænʒɹəl, itʃ ə ðɛm fɪld wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən bɹɪsəlɪŋ wɪð æŋɡɝ.

Androl released the One Power. Coteren had had his laugh; he would be satisfied. Unfortunately, Androl felt men seize the Source behind him. Jonneth, Canler and Nalaam stepped up beside Androl, each of them filled with the One Power and bristling with anger.

ðə mɛn u hæd bɪn iɾɪŋ stʊɾ ʌp, itʃ hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹs əz wɛl. ðəɹ wɝ twaɪs əz mɛni ʌv əm əz ðəɹ wɝ ʌv ænʒɹəl ɛs fɹɛnz. koʊɾɝən smɝkt.

The men who had been eating stood up, each holding the Source as well. There were twice as many of them as there were of Androl s friends. Coteren smirked.

ænʒɹəl aɪd kænlɝ ən ði ʌðɝz. "naʊ lædz," hi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hænd, "æʃəmən koʊɾɝən wɑz dʒʌs duɪŋ wʌt ðə l ɔɹɾɝd hɪm. hi ɛs tʃɹaɪ-ɪŋ tə meɪk mi mæd soʊ əl pʊʃ maɪsɛlf."

Androl eyed Canler and the others. "Now lads," he said, raising a hand, "Asha'man Coteren was just doing what the M'Hael ordered him. He s try-ing to make me mad so I'll push myself."

ðə tu ɡɹups hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ði ɪntɛnsəɾi ʌv ðɛɹ lɑkt ɡeɪzəz ɹaɪvəl ðəɾ ə ðə paʊɝ wɪðɪn ðɛm. ðən dʒɑnɪθ ɹilis ðə sɔɹs. ðɪs kɑz næləm tə də laɪkwaɪz, ən faɪnəli ɡɹʌf kænlɝ tɝn əweɪ. koʊɾɝən læft.

The two groups hesitated. The intensity of their locked gazes rivaled that of the Power within them. Then Jonneth released the Source. This caused Nalaam to do likewise, and finally gruff Canler turned away. Coteren laughed.

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs," kænlɝ mʌɾɝd əz ðə ɡɹup ə ðɛm wɔkt ɔf. hi ʃɑɾ ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "doʊn laɪk ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. waɪd jə stɑp ʌs, ænʒɹəl?"

"I don't like this," Canler muttered as the group of them walked off. He shot a glance over his shoulder. "Don't like it at all. Why'd you stop us, Androl?"

"bɪkɔz ðeɪɾ əv meɪd ɹʌbəl ʌv əs fæstɝ ðən jə kən kɝs, kænlɝ" ænʒɹəl snæpt.

"Because they'd have made rubble of us faster than you can curse, Canler" Androl snapped.

"laɪt, mæn! aɪ kən bɛɹli tʃænəl wɝθ ə bin, ən əmɝɪn hæzən bɪn hɪɹ ə mʌnθ jɛt. dʒɑnɪθs lɝnɪŋ fæst, bʌt wi ɔl noʊ hiz nɛvɝ æktʃəli  fɔt wɪð ðə paʊɝ bɪfɔɹ, ən hæf ə koʊ-tʃɹənz mɛn sɔ bæɾəl bɪniθ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən! jə ɹɪli θɪŋk jə ən næləm kəd hændəl tɛn mɛn, vɝtʃuəli ɑn jəɹ oʊn?"

"Light, man! I can barely channel worth a bean, and Emarin hasn't been here a month yet. Jonneth's learning fast, but we all know he's never actually fought with the Power before, and half of Co-teren's men saw battle beneath the Lord Dragon! You really think you and Nalaam could handle ten men, virtually on your own?"

kænlɝ kəntɪnjud tə bɹɪsəl, mʌɾɝɪŋ, bʌt lɛt ði ɑɹɡjəmən dʒɹɑp.

Canler continued to bristle, muttering, but let the argument drop.

"mɑkɑʃək nɑ fəmɑlɑʃtən mɔɹkeɪs," næləm mʌmbəld, "dɛlf tɑkɑk-sɑki mɪɹ!" hi læf tə hɪmsɛlf, aɪz waɪld. ɪt wɑzn ə læŋɡwədʒ ænʒɹəl nu- - ɪt wɑzn ði oʊl tʌŋ, ðət wɑz fəɹ sɝɾən.

"Makashak Na famalashten morkase," Nalaam mumbled, "delf takak-saki mere!" He laughed to himself, eyes wild. It wasn't a language Androl knew- - it wasn't the Old Tongue, that was for certain.

ɪt pɹɑbli wɑzn ivən ə læŋɡwədʒ əɾ ɔl.

It probably wasn't even a language at all.

nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. næləm əkeɪʒənəli kækəl tə hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɡɪbɝɪʃ. ɪf æskt əbaʊɾ ɪt, hid kleɪm hid spoʊkən ɪn pleɪn ɔɹɾənɛɹi wɝdz. ði aʊtbɝst sim tə dɪskɑmfɪɾ əmɝɪn ən dʒɑnɪθ ə ɡɹeɪt dil. ðeɪ hædn ɛvɝ sin fɹɛnz ɡoʊ mæɾ ən kɪl ðoʊz ɝaʊn ðɛm. laɪt sɛn ðət ðeɪd nɛvɝ əv tə si ɪt, naʊ. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ænʒɹəl θɔɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən fəɹ livɪŋ əm əloʊn, ðə klɛnzɪŋ ɝn ælθɹ ɹɪdɛmpʃən. tʃænəlɪŋ wɑz seɪf naʊ.

None of the others said anything. Nalaam occasionally cackled to himself in gibberish. If asked about it, he'd claim he'd spoken in plain ordinary words. The outburst seemed to discomfit Emarin and Jonneth a great deal. They hadn't ever seen friends go mad and kill those around them. Light send that they'd never have to see it, now. Whatever else Androl thought of the Lord Dragon for leaving them alone, the cleansing earned al'Thor redemption. Channeling was safe now.

ɔɹ, ət list, ɪt wɑz seɪfɝ. tʃænəlɪŋ wəd nɛvɝ bi seɪf, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli naʊ wɪð teɪm pʊʃɪŋ ðɛm.

Or, at least, it was safer. Channeling would never be safe, particularly now with Taim pushing them.

"mɔɹ ən mɔɹ pipəl ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ ðoʊz bɝnɪŋ pɝsənəl lɛsənz fɹəm teɪm," næləm mʌɾɝd əz ðeɪ wɔk tə ðə ʃeɪɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz. "nɛnsənz səksɛs əz ðə mɛn iɡɝ. wiv lɔst ə ɡʊd dʌzən tə teɪmz saɪɾ ɪn ðə læs tʃu wiks. sun ðəɹ woʊn bi ɛniwʌn lɛf bɪsaɪdz əs hɪɹ. aɪm əfɹeɪd tə tɔk tə hæf ðə mɛn aɪ juz tə tʃɹʌst."

"More and more people are taking those burning personal lessons from Taim," Nalaam muttered as they walked to the shade of the trees. "Nensen's success has the men eager. We've lost a good dozen to Taim's side in the last tew weeks. Soon there won't be anyone left besides us here. I'm afraid to talk to half the men I used to trust."

"nɔɹli ɪz tʃɹʌstwɝði," kænlɝ sɛd. "ɛvɪn hɑɹdlɪn, tu."

"Norley is trustworthy," Canler said. "Evin Hardlin, too."

"ðæts ə smɔl lɪst," næləm sɛd. "tu smɔl."

"That's a small list," Nalaam said. "Too small."

"ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɑɹ wɪð ʌs," dʒɑnɪθ sɛd. "tə ə mæn."

"The Two Rivers men are with us," Jonneth said. "To a man."

"stɪl ə smɔl lɪst," næləm sɛd. "ænd nɑɾ ə fʊl æʃəmən əmʌŋ ʌs."

"Still a small list," Nalaam said. "And not a full Asha'man among us."

ðeɪ ɔl lʊk tə ænʒɹəl. hi ɡlæns bæk ət teɪmz lækiz, læf-ɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əɡɛn.

They all looked to Androl. He glanced back at Taim's lackeys, laugh-ing among themselves again.

"wʌt, ænʒɹəl?"

"What, Androl?"

næləm æskt. "nɑt gɑnə tʃæstaɪz əs fəɹ tɔkɪŋ laɪk ðæt?"

Nalaam asked. "Not going to chastise us for talking like that?"

"laɪk wʌt?" ænʒɹəl æskt, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət ðɛm.

"Like what?" Androl asked, looking back at them.

"laɪk ɪts əs əɡɛns ðɛm."

"Like it's us against them."

"aɪ dɪdnt wɑn jə lædz tə ɡɛt jʊɹsɛlvz kɪld əɹ ɪmpɹɪzənd, bʌt ðət dʌzn min aɪ doʊn si ə pɹɑbləm." hi ɡlæns bæk ət ðɛm. "aɪ, ðɛɹz tʃɹʌbəl hɪɹ, bɹuɪŋ laɪk ə stɔɹm."

"I didn't want you lads to get yourselves killed or imprisoned, but that doesn't mean I don't see a problem." He glanced back at them. "Aye, there's trouble here, brewing like a storm."

"ðə mɛn u teɪk teɪmz pɹaɪvət lɛsənz lɝn tu kwɪkli," næləm sɛd. "nɛnsən wɑz bɛɹli paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf tə bi kənsɪɾɝd fəɹ dɛɾəkeɪtəd dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm əɡoʊ. naʊ hiz fʊl æʃəmən.

"The men who take Taim's private lessons learn too quickly," Nalaam said. "Nensen was barely powerful enough to be considered for Dedicated just a short time ago. Now he's full Asha'man.

sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. ən ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ. waɪ dɪd teɪm əɡɹi tə lɛɾ əm bɑn ʌs?

Something very strange is going on. And those Aes Sedai. Why did Taim agree to let them bond us?

jə noʊ hiz pɹətɛktəɾ ɔl ə hɪz feɪvɹɪts baɪ stɑpɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm tʃuzɪŋ ɛni mæn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən pɪn. bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ əl də ɪf wʌn tʃuzəz mi. aɪm nɑt gɑnə bi pʊɾ ɑn səm ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛs stʃɹɪŋ."

You know he's protected all of his favorites by stopping the Aes Sedai from choosing any man with the Dragon pin. Burn me, but I don't know what I'll do if one chooses me. I'm not going to be put on some Aes Sedai s string."

ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl mʌɾɝz əbaʊt ðæt.

There were several mutters about that.

"teɪmz mɛn spɹɛd ɹumɝz əmʌŋ ðə nukʌmɝz," dʒɑnɪθ sɛd sɔfli. "ðeɪ tɔk əbaʊt ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ən haʊ hi dʒɹoʊv ɡʊd mɛn tə tɝn tʃɹeɪɾɝ. ðeɪ seɪ hiz əbændən ʌs, ən ðət hiz ɡɔn mæd. ðə l dʌznt wɑn ðoʊz ɹumɝz pɔɪntɪŋ bæk tə hɪm, bʌt bɝn mi ɪf i ɪzən ðə sɔɹs ə ðɛm ɔl."

"Taim's men spread rumors among the newcomers," Jonneth said softly. "They talk about the Lord Dragon, and how he drove good men to turn traitor. They say he's abandoned us, and that he's gone mad. The M'Hael doesn't want those rumors pointing back to him, but burn me if he isn't the source of them all."

"meɪbi hiz ɹaɪt," kænlɝ sɛd. ði ʌðɝz lʊkt əɾ ɪm ʃɑɹpli, ən ðə lɛðɝi mæn skaʊld.

"Maybe he's right," Canler said. The others looked at him sharply, and the leathery man scowled.

"aɪm nɑt seɪɪŋ ðəɾ aɪm gɑnə ɡoʊ dʒʌmp ɪndə teɪmz kæmp. bʌt ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən? wʌɾ əz i dʌn fəɹ ʌs? simz laɪk hiz fɝɡɑɾən əbaʊt ðɪs pleɪs. meɪbi hiz mæd."

"I'm not saying that I'm going to go jump into Taim's camp. But the Lord Dragon? What has he done for us? Seems like he's forgotten about this place. Maybe he is mad."

"hiz nɑt," əmɝɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ mɛɾ ɪm dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ aɪ keɪm hɪɹ."

"He's not," Emarin said, shaking his head. "I met him just before I came here."

ði ʌðɝz lʊkt ət hɪm, sɝpɹaɪzd.

The others looked at him, surprised.

"hi ɪmpɹɛs mi," əmɝɪn sɛd. "jʌŋ, bʌt wɪð ə paʊɝfəl wɪl. aɪ tʃɹʌs hɪm. laɪt! aɪ bɛɹli spoʊk wɪð ɪm ə hæf-dʌzən taɪmz, bʌɾ aɪ tʃɹʌs hɪm."

"He impressed me," Emarin said. "Young, but with a powerful will. I trust him. Light! I barely spoke with him a half-dozen times, but I trust him."

ði ʌðɝz sloʊli nɑɾəd.

The others slowly nodded.

"bɝn mi," kænlɝ sɛd, "aɪ səpoʊz ðæts ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi. bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ hid lɪsən! aɪ hɝd lɑɡən kɝsɪŋ ðət ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən woʊn hɪɹ ɪm wən i ɡɪvz wɔɹnɪŋz əbaʊt teɪm."

"Burn me," Canler said, "I suppose that's good enough for me. But I wish he'd listen! I heard Logain cursing that the Lord Dragon won't hear him when he gives warnings about Taim."

"æn ɪf wi ɡeɪv ɪm ɛvəɾəns?" dʒɑnɪθ æskt. "wʌɾ ɪf wi kəd faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ðət pɹuvz ðət teɪm ɪz ʌp tə noʊ ɡʊd?"

"And if we gave him evidence?" Jonneth asked. "What if we could find something that proves that Taim is up to no good?"

"sʌmθɪŋ ɪz stʃɹeɪnʒ əbaʊt nɛnsən," næləm ɹɪpiɾɪd. "æn ðət kæʃ. wɛɹ dɪɾ i ivən kʌm fɹʌm, ən haʊ dɪɾ i ɡɹoʊ soʊ paʊɝfəl soʊ kwɪkli? wʌɾ ɪf, wən lɑɡən ɹɪtɝnd, wi hæɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fəɹ hɪm. əɹ ɪf wi kəd teɪk ɪt tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən dɝɛkli . . ."

"Something is strange about Nensen," Nalaam repeated. "And that Kash. Where did he even come from, and how did he grow so powerful so quickly? What if, when Logain returned, we had information for him. Or if we could take it to the Lord Dragon directly . . ."

ðə ɡɹup tɝn tə ænʒɹəl. waɪ dɪd ðeɪ lʊk tə hɪm, ðə wikəst ə ðɛm? ɔl i kəd də wɑz kɹieɪt ɡeɪtweɪz. ðət wɑz wɛɹ koʊɾɝənz nɪkneɪm fəɹ ænʒɹəl hæd kʌm fɹʌm. peɪdʒbɔɪ. ði oʊnli θɪŋ i wɑz ɡʊd fəɹ wɑz dɪlɪvɝɪŋ mɛsədʒəz, teɪkɪŋ pipəl pleɪsəz.

The group turned to Androl. Why did they look to him, the weakest of them? All he could do was create gateways. That was where Coteren's nickname for Androl had come from. Pageboy. The only thing he was good for was delivering messages, taking people places.

bʌt ði ʌðɝz lʊk tə hɪm. fəɹ wʌn ɹizən əɹ ənʌðɝ, ðeɪ lʊk tə hɪm.

But the others looked to him. For one reason or another, they looked to him.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "lɛts si wʌt wi kən faɪnd. bɹɪŋ ɛvɪn, hɑɹd-lɪn ən nɔɹli ɪndə ðɪs bʌt doʊn tɛl ɛniwʌn ɛls, nɑɾ ivən ði ʌðɝ tu ɹɪvɝz lædz. doʊn ɹaɪl teɪm əɹ ɪz mɛn . . . bʌɾ ɪf jə də faɪn sʌmθɪŋ, bɹɪŋ ɪt tə mi. ən əl si ɪf aɪ kən faɪn ə weɪ tə kɑntæk lɑɡən, əɹ ət lis faɪnd wɛɹ i wɛnt."

"All right," Androl said. "Let's see what we can find. Bring Evin, Hard-lin and Norley into this but don't tell anyone else, not even the other Two Rivers lads. Don't rile Taim or his men . . . but if you do find something, bring it to me. And I'll see if I can find a way to contact Logain, or at least find where he went."

itʃ mæn nɑɾəd, sɑmbɝ. laɪt hɛlp əs ɪf wɝ ɹɔŋ, ænʒɹəl θɔt, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət teɪmz feɪvɹɪts. ən laɪt hɛlp əs mɔɹ ɪf wɝ ɹaɪt.

Each man nodded, somber. Light help us if we're wrong, Androl thought, looking back at Taim's favorites. And Light help us more if we're right.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 47

eɪ titʃɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ


A Teaching Chamber

feɪl sæɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli ətɑp deɪlaɪt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip hɝsɛlf fɹəm twɪtʃɪŋ əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ splɪt ði ɛɹ. ə bɹaʊnɪŋ mɛdoʊ leɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd; ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz ɪmiɾiətli slɪp θɹu tə skaʊt.

Faile sat impatiently atop Daylight, trying to keep herself from twitching as the gateway split the air. A browning meadow lay on the other side; Gaul and the Maidens immediately slipped through to scout.
