"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jə doʊnt wɑnə kʌm?" pɛɹɪn æskt ɡɑləd, hu stʊd nɪɹbaɪ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə pɹəsɛʃən wɪð ɑɹmz klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk.

"Are you certain you don't want to come?" Perrin asked Galad, who stood nearby, watching the procession with arms clasped behind his back.

"noʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd. "maɪ mil wɪð ɪleɪn wɑz səfɪʃən fəɹ əs tə kætʃ ʌp."

"No," Galad said. "My meal with Elayne was sufficient for us to catch up."

"sut jɝsɛlf," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi tɝn tə feɪl ən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

"Suit yourself," Perrin said. He turned to Faile and gestured to the gateway.

ʃi kɪk deɪlaɪɾ ɪndə moʊʃən. ɪt wɑz taɪm, ət lɔŋ læst, tə feɪs ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ, ən ʃi hæd tə wɝk tə kənteɪn əɹ nɝvəsnəs. pɛɹɪn pæs θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪð hɝ; ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, keɪɛmlɪn wɑz kloʊz, ðə ɡɹæn sɪɾi tɑp baɪ pik taʊɝz ən bænɝz ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪt, pæləs ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ. loʊ keɪɛmlɪn, wɪtʃ spɹɔld aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz, wɑz ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɪɾi ʌv ɪts oʊn.

She kicked Daylight into motion. It was time, at long last, to face the Queen of Andor, and she had to work to contain her nervousness. Perrin passed through the gateway with her; on the other side, Caemlyn was close, the grand city topped by peaked towers and banners of red and white, palace rising in the center. Low Caemlyn, which sprawled outside the city walls, was a growing city of its own.

pɛɹɪn ɛs pɹəsɛʃən fɑloʊɾ əm aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ; ɪt hæd bɪn kɛɹfəli plæn tə lʊk ɪmpɹɛsɪv, bʌt nɑt hɑstəl. æliændɝ wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡɑɹdzmɪn. ə hʌnʒɹəd tu ɹɪvɝz ɑɹtʃɝz wɪð ənstʃɹʌŋ lɔŋboʊz kæɹid laɪk steɪvz. ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪvz ə ðə wʊlf ɡɑɹd, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ kəntɪnʒənt ə maɪnɝ kɛɹhin noʊbɪləɾi, ðə kʌlɝd slæʃɪz ɑn ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz kɹieɪɾəd fɹəm klɔθ pɝtʃəst ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz.

Perrin s procession followed them out of the gateway; it had been carefully planned to look impressive, but not hostile. Alliandre with a hundred guardsmen. A hundred Two Rivers archers with unstrung longbows carried like staves. A hundred representatives of the Wolf Guard, including a large contingent of minor Cairhien nobility, the colored slashes on their uniforms created from cloth purchased in Whitebridge. And, of course, Gaul and the Maidens.

ɡɹeɪɾi keɪm læst. ðə mæn wɔɹ ə nitli pɹɛs blæk koʊt, hɪz dɛɾi-keɪtɪd pɪn pɑlɪʃt ən ɡlimɪŋ ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ. hi ɪmiɾiətli lʊkt wɛstwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə blæk taʊɝ. hid tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ ðəɹ ɝliɝ ɪn ðə deɪ, wən pɛɹɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm pɝmɪʃən. ɪt hædnt wɝkt.

Grady came last. The man wore a neatly pressed black coat, his Dedi-cated pin polished and gleaming on the high collar. He immediately looked westward, toward the Black Tower. He'd tried to make a gateway there earlier in the day, when Perrin had given him permission. It hadn't worked.

pɛɹɪn wɑz dɪstɝbd baɪ ðæt. hi ɪntɛndəd tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt sun, tənaɪɾ əɹ təmɑɹoʊ naɪɾ ət ðə leɪɾəst.

Perrin was disturbed by that. He intended to investigate soon, tonight or tomorrow night at the latest.

ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz fɔɹmd ʌp ɝaʊn pɛɹɪn ən feɪl, ən ðə pɹəsɛʃən muv daʊn ɑntu ðə ɹoʊd, ɑɹɡændə ən ə skwɑɾ ə pɛɹɪnz wʊlf ɡɑɹdz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əhɛd tə ənaʊns ðɛm. ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm muvd əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊɾ əɾ ə ɹiɡəl peɪs. keɪɛmlɪnz spɹɔlɪŋ ɡɹoʊθ wɑz ivən wɝs ðən ðəɾ ʌv waɪtbɹɪdʒ. sɛvɹəl ɑɹmiz kæmp nɪɹ loʊ keɪɛmlɪn. pɹɑbli səpɔɹɾəd baɪ ðə vɛɹiəs lɔɹdz u hæd səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪnz əsɛn tə ðə θɹoʊn.

Gaul and the Maidens formed up around Perrin and Faile, and the procession moved down onto the road, Arganda and a squad of Perrin's Wolf Guards riding ahead to announce them. The rest of them moved along the road at a regal pace. Caemlyn's sprawling growth was even worse than that of Whitebridge. Several armies camped near Low Caemlyn. Probably supported by the various lords who had supported Elayne's ascent to the throne.

ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪstɪŋkt ɪɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi hɪɹ. ðə klaʊdz bɹoʊk ɝaʊn keɪɛmlɪn. ðə klaʊd kʌvɝ hæd bɪn soʊ junəvɝsəl ɛlswɛɹ ðət feɪl stɑɹɾəd əpɑn siɪŋ ðɪs. ðə klaʊdz fɔɹmd ən oʊpən sɝkəl əbʌv ðə sɪɾi, ɪɹəli ivən. ɑɹɡændə ən ðə wʊlf ɡɑɹdz ɹɪtɝnd. "ðeɪ wɪl ɹəsiv ʌs, maɪ lɔɹd, maɪ leɪɾi," hi ənaʊnst.

There was a distinct irregularity here. The clouds broke around Caemlyn. The cloud cover had been so universal elsewhere that Faile started upon seeing this. The clouds formed an open circle above the city, eerily even. Arganda and the Wolf Guards returned. "They will receive us, my Lord, my Lady," he announced.

feɪl ən pɛɹɪn ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns əz ðə ɡɹup meɪɾ ɪts weɪ daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. ðeɪ hæd dɪskʌs ðə kʌmɪŋ miɾɪŋ dʌzənz ə taɪmz oʊvɝ; ðəɹ wɑzn ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ tə seɪ. pɛɹɪn hæd waɪzli ɡɪvən əɹ ðə lɛɾ ɪn ðə dɪpləmæɾɪk nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. ðə wɝl kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd wɔɹ bɪtwin ændɝ ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. nɑt naʊ.

Faile and Perrin rode in silence as the group made its way down the road. They had discussed the coming meeting dozens of times over; there wasn't anything more to say. Perrin had wisely given her the lead in the diplomatic negotiations. The world could not afford war between Andor and the Two Rivers. Not now.

əz ðeɪ pæs θɹu ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts, pɛɹɪn ən ði il ɡɹu mɔɹ əlɝt. ʃi sʌfɝd ðɛɹ oʊvɝpɹoʊtɛktɪvnəs ɪn saɪləns. haʊ lɔŋ wəɾ əɹ kæptʃɝ baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ lum oʊvɝ əɹ laɪf? ət taɪmz, ɪt sim pɛɹɪn wɑz loʊθ tə lɛɾ əɹ juz ðə pɹɪvi wɪθaʊt fɔɹ dʌzən ɡɑɹdz.

As they passed through the city gates, Perrin and the Aiel grew more alert. She suffered their overprotectiveness in silence. How long would her capture by the Shaido loom over her life? At times, it seemed Perrin was loath to let her use the privy without four dozen guards.

ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ðə stʃɹits timd wɪð pipəl, ðə bɪldɪŋz ən mɑɹkəts pækt. ɹɛfjus wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə paɪl ʌp, ən ə fɹaɪɾənɪŋ nʌmbɝ ə ɝtʃənz muv θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz. kɹɪɝz jɛld əbaʊt ðə deɪnʒɝəs taɪmz, səm pɝhæps ɪn ði ɛmplɔɪ ʌv ðə mɝtʃəns, ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ pipəl tə hɔɹd. pɛɹɪnz pipəl hæd bɑt fud hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪkspɛnsɪv; sun, ɪleɪn wəd nid tə sʌbsɪdaɪz ɪt, ɪf ʃi hædn ɔlɹɛɾi. haʊ ɡʊd wɝ ðə ɹɔɪəl stɔɹz?

Inside the walls, the streets teemed with people, the buildings and markets packed. Refuse was beginning to pile up, and a frightening number of urchins moved through the crowds. Criers yelled about the dangerous times, some perhaps in the employ of the merchants, encouraging people to hoard. Perrin's people had bought food here, but it was expensive; soon, Elayne would need to subsidize it, if she hadn't already. How good were the royal stores?

ðeɪ pæs θɹu ðə nu sɪɾi, ðən ɛntɝd ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, klaɪmɪŋ ðə hɪl tə ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf. ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd stʊɾ əɾ ətɛnʃən ɪn ðɛɹ ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt tɑbɝdz ən bɝnɪʃt pleɪt-ænd- meɪl aʊtsaɪd ðə pæləs ɡeɪts ɪn ðə pɹɪstin waɪt pæləs wɔlz.

They passed through the New City, then entered the Inner City, climbing the hill to the Palace itself. The Queen's Guard stood at attention in their red-and-white tabards and burnished plate-and- mail outside the Palace gates in the pristine white Palace walls.

wʌns pæs ðə ɡeɪts, ðeɪ dɪsmaʊntɪd. ə fɔɹs ʌv wʌn hʌnʒɹəd kəntɪn-ʊɛɾ ɑn wɪð pɛɹɪn ən feɪl ɪndə ðə pæləs. ɔl ə ði il, ən ə smɔlɝ ɑnɝ ɡɑɹd fɹəm itʃ kəntɪnʒənt. ðə pæləs hɔlweɪz wɝ waɪd bʌt ðət mɛni pipəl stɪl meɪd feɪl fil kɹaʊɾəd. ðə pæθ ʃi ən pɛɹɪn wɝ lɛɾ əlɔŋ wɑz ə dɪfɹənt weɪ tə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum ðən ʃid teɪkən bɪfɔɹ. waɪ nɑt juz ðə dɝɛkt weɪ?

Once past the gates, they dismounted. A force of one hundred contin-ued on with Perrin and Faile into the Palace. All of the Aiel, and a smaller honor guard from each contingent. The Palace hallways were wide but that many people still made Faile feel crowded. The path she and Perrin were led along was a different way to the throne room than she'd taken before. Why not use the direct way?

ɪt sim ðət lɪɾəl hæd tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊt ðə pæləs sɪns ɹændz taɪm ɹʌl-ɪŋ ɪt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ il naʊ - seɪv fəɹ ðə wʌnz pɛɹɪn hæd bɹɔt. ðə seɪm nɛɹoʊ ɹɛd ɹʌɡ ɹæn daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə hɔlweɪ, ðə seɪm ɝnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz, ðə seɪm mɪɹɝz ɑn ðə wɔlz tə ɡɪv ən ɪluʒən ʌv ɡɹeɪɾɝ saɪz.

It seemed that little had changed about the Palace since Rand's time rul-ing it. There were no Aiel now - save for the ones Perrin had brought. The same narrow red rug ran down the middle of the hallway, the same urns at the corners, the same mirrors on the walls to give an illusion of greater size.

ə stʃɹʌktʃɝ laɪk ðɪs kəd stæn ənɔltɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə sɛntʃɝiz, peɪɪŋ lɪɾəl ətɛnʃən tə huz fit tʃɹɑd ðə ɹʌɡz ən huz bæksaɪd wɔɹm ðə θɹoʊn. ɪn wʌn jɪɹz taɪm, ðɪs pæləs hæd noʊn mɔɹɡeɪs, wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən faɪnəli ɪleɪn.

A structure like this could stand unaltered over the centuries, paying little attention to whose feet trod the rugs and whose backside warmed the throne. In one year's time, this palace had known Morgase, one of the Forsaken, the Dragon Reborn and finally Elayne.

ɪn fækt, feɪl hæf-ɪkspɛktəd - əz ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ðə kɔɹnɝ tə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum - tə faɪn ɹænd laʊnʒɪŋ ɑn ɪz dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn, ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ hæf-spɪɹ hɛld ɪn ðə kɹʊk ə hɪz ɑɹm, ə ɡlɪmɝ ə mædnəs ɪn ɪz aɪz. haʊɛvɝ, ðə dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn hæd bɪn ɹimuvd, ən ðə laɪən θɹoʊn əɡɛn hɛld ɪts kwin. ɹænd hæd sɛt ðət θɹoʊn əsaɪɾ ən pɹətɛktəɾ ɪt, laɪk ə flaʊɝ i ɪntɛndəd tə pɹizɛn tə ə fjutʃɝ lʌv.

In fact, Faile half-expected - as they rounded the corner to the throne room - to find Rand lounging on his Dragon Throne, that strange half-spear held in the crook of his arm, a glimmer of madness in his eyes. However, the Dragon Throne had been removed, and the Lion Throne again held its queen. Rand had set that throne aside and protected it, like a flower he intended to present to a future love.

ðə kwin wɑz ə jʌŋɡɝ vɝʒən ə hɝ mʌðɝ. tʃɹu, ɪleɪnz feɪs hæɾ æŋɡəlz ðət wɝ mɔɹ dɛləkət ðən mɔɹɡeɪsəz. bʌt ʃi hæd ðət seɪm ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ ən ðət seɪm stʌnɪŋ bjuɾi. ʃi wɑz tɔl, ən wɑz ʃoʊɪŋ əɹ pɹɛɡnənsi ət ðə bɛli ən θɹu ðə tʃɛst.

The Queen was a younger version of her mother. True, Elayne's face had angles that were more delicate than Morgase's. But she had that same red-gold hair and that same stunning beauty. She was tall, and was showing her pregnancy at the belly and through the chest.

ðə θɹoʊn ɹum wɑz suɾəbli ɔɹneɪt, wɪð ɡɪldɪd wʊd tʃɹɪm ən nɛɹoʊ pɪlɝz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝz, pɹɑbli ɔɹnəmɛntəl. ɪleɪn kɛp ðə ɹum bɛɾɝ lɪt ðən ɹænd hæd, stænd-læmps bɝnɪŋ bɹaɪtli.

The throne room was suitably ornate, with gilded wood trim and narrow pillars in the corners, probably ornamental. Elayne kept the room better lit than Rand had, stand-lamps burning brightly.

mɔɹɡeɪs hɝsɛlf stʊɾ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə θɹoʊn ɑn ðə ɹaɪt saɪd, ən eɪt mɛmbɝz ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd stʊɾ ɑn ðə lɛft. səm lɛsɝ noʊbəlz laɪn ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹum, wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð kin ətɛnʃən.

Morgase herself stood at the base of the throne on the right side, and eight members of the Queen's Guard stood on the left. Some lesser nobles lined the sides of the room, watching with keen attention.

ɪleɪn lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn əɹ θɹoʊn əz pɛɹɪn, feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɛntɝd. feɪl kɝtsid, ʌv kɔɹs, ən pɛɹɪn baʊd. nɑɾ ə loʊ baʊ, bʌɾ ə baʊ nʌnðəlɛs. baɪ ɝeɪnʒmənt, æliændɝ kɝtsid dipɝ ðən feɪl hæd. ðət wəɾ ɪmiɾiətli sɛɾ ɪleɪn θɪŋkɪŋ.

Elayne leaned forward on her throne as Perrin, Faile and the others entered. Faile curtsied, of course, and Perrin bowed. Not a low bow, but a bow nonetheless. By arrangement, Alliandre curtsied deeper than Faile had. That would immediately set Elayne thinking.

ði əfɪʃəl pɝpəs ə ðɪs vɪzət wɑz ə kɑməndeɪʃən baɪ ðə kɹaʊn, ə θæŋks tə pɛɹɪn ən feɪl fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ bæk mɔɹɡeɪs. ðət wɑz dʒʌst ən æfɛkteɪʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. ðɛɹ ɹil ɹizən fəɹ miɾɪŋ wɑz tə dɪskʌs ðə fjutʃɝ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. bʌt ðət wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə dɛləkət ɡoʊl ðət niðɝ kəd spik ʌv aʊtʃɹaɪt, ət lis nɑɾ ət fɝst. mɪɹli steɪɾɪŋ ði əbdʒɛktɪv wəd ɹɪvil tu mʌtʃ tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd.

The official purpose of this visit was a commendation by the Crown, a thanks to Perrin and Faile for bringing back Morgase. That was just an affectation, of course. Their real reason for meeting was to discuss the future of the Two Rivers. But that was the sort of delicate goal that neither could speak of outright, at least not at first. Merely stating the objective would reveal too much to the other side.

"lɛɾ ɪt bi noʊn," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪð ə mjuzɪkəl vɔɪs, "ðæt ðə θɹoʊn wɛlkəmz ju, leɪɾi zɑɹin ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. kwin æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɛɝɪn. pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." noʊ jus ə taɪɾəl fəɹ hɪm. "lɛɾ ɪt bi pɹoʊkleɪmd ɪn pɝsən əɹ ɡɹæɾətud tə jə fəɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ əɹ mʌðɝ. jəɹ dɪlədʒəns ɪn ðɪs mæɾɝ ɝnz jə ðə kɹaʊnz dipəst əpɹiʃieɪʃən."

"Let it be known," Elayne said with a musical voice, "that the throne welcomes you, Lady Zarine ni Bashere t'Aybara. Queen Alliandre Maritha Kigaarin. Perrin Aybara." No use of title for him. "Let it be proclaimed in person our gratitude to you for returning our mother. Your diligence in this matter earns you the Crown's deepest appreciation."

"θæŋk ju, jəɹ mædʒəsti," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ɪz juʒəwəl ɡɹʌfnəs. feɪl hæd spoʊkən tə hɪm ət lɛŋθ əbaʊt nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪspɛns wɪð ðə fɔɹmæləɾi əɹ sɛɹəmoʊni.

"Thank you, Your Majesty," Perrin said with his usual gruffness. Faile had spoken to him at length about not trying to dispense with the formality or ceremony.

"wi wɪl dɪklɛɹ ə deɪ ʌv sɛləbɹeɪʃən fəɹ maɪ mʌðɝz seɪf ɹɪtɝn," ɪleɪn kəntɪnjud. "æn fəɹ əɹ . . . ɹɛstɝeɪʃən tə pɹɑpɝ stæɾəs."

"We will declare a day of celebration for my mother's safe return," Elayne continued. "And for her . . . restoration to proper status."

wɛl, ðət pɔz mɛn ɪleɪn wɑz dɪspliz tə noʊ ðəɾ əɹ mʌðɝ hæd bɪn tʃɹiɾəd əz ə sɝvənt. ʃi hæd tə ɹilaɪz ðət pɛɹɪn ən feɪl hædnt noʊn wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ, bʌɾ ə kwin kəd stɪl kleɪm ɪndɪɡneɪʃən fəɹ sətʃ ən ɪvɛnt. ɪt wɑz ən ɛdʒ ðæt, pɝhæps, ʃi plæn tə juz.

Well, that pause meant Elayne was displeased to know that her mother had been treated as a servant. She had to realize that Perrin and Faile hadn't known what they were doing, but a queen could still claim indignation for such an event. It was an edge that, perhaps, she planned to use.

pɝhæps feɪl wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ɪndə ðə kɑmɛns, bʌt ʃi kʊdn hɛlp ɪt. ɪn mɛni weɪz, biɪŋ ə leɪɾi wɑz mʌtʃ laɪk biɪŋ ə mɝtʃənt, ən ʃi hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪnd wɛl fəɹ boʊθ ɹoʊlz.

Perhaps Faile was reading too much into the comments, but she couldn't help it. In many ways, being a lady was much like being a merchant, and she had been trained well for both roles.

"faɪnəli," ɪleɪn sɛd, "wi kʌm tə ðə pɝpəs ʌv əɹ miɾɪŋ. leɪɾi bæʃɪɹ, mæstɝ eɪbɑɹə. ɪz ðəɹ ə bun jə wəɾ æsk ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə ɡɪf juv ɡɪvən tə ændɝ?"

"Finally," Elayne said, "we come to the purpose of our meeting. Lady Bashere, Master Aybara. Is there a boon you would ask in return for the gift you have given to Andor?"

pɛɹɪn ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz hæmɝ, ðən lʊk tə feɪl kwɛstʃən-ɪŋli. ɑbviəsli, ɪleɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə æsk fəɹ ɪm tə bi neɪm fɔɹməli ə lɔɹd. ɔɹ, pɝhæps, tə æsk fɔɹbɛɹəns fəɹ ɪmpɝsəneɪɾɪŋ wʌn, əlɔŋ wɪð ə fɔɹməl pɑɹɾən. iðɝ dɝɛkʃən kəd bi ə ɹɪzʌlt ə ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

Perrin rested his hand on his hammer, then looked to Faile question-ingly. Obviously, Elayne expected them to ask for him to be named formally a lord. Or, perhaps, to ask forbearance for impersonating one, along with a formal pardon. Either direction could be a result of this conversation.

feɪl wɑz tɛmptəd tə dɪmæn ðə fɝst. ɪt wəd bi ə sɪmpəl ænsɝ. bʌt pɝhæps tu sɪmpəl; ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz feɪl hæd tə noʊ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd pɹəsid. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti," feɪl sɛd, kɛɹfəli, "maɪt wi dɪskʌs ðɪs bun ɪn ə mɔɹ ɪntəmət sɛɾɪŋ?"

Faile was tempted to demand the first. It would be a simple answer. But perhaps too simple; there were things Faile had to know before they could proceed. "Your Majesty," Faile said, carefully, "might we discuss this boon in a more intimate setting?"

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ðət səm θɔt - ət lis θɝɾi sɛkənz' wɝθ, wɪtʃ simd ən ɪnfɪnəɾi. "vɛɹi wɛl. maɪ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ɪz pɹipɛɹd."

Elayne gave that some thought - at least thirty seconds' worth, which seemed an infinity. "Very well. My sitting room is prepared."

feɪl nɑɾəd, ən ə sɝvən oʊpən ə smɔl dɔɹ ɑn ðə lɛft-hænd wɔl ə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum. pɛɹɪn wɔk təwɔɹɾ ɪt, ðən hɛld ʌp ə hæn tə ɡɔl, su-lɪn ən ɑɹɡændə. "weɪt hɪɹ." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ɡɹeɪɾi. "ju, tu."

Faile nodded, and a servant opened a small door on the left-hand wall of the throne room. Perrin walked toward it, then held up a hand to Gaul, Su-lin and Arganda. "Wait here." He hesitated, glancing at Grady. "You, too."

nʌn ə ðɛm sim tə laɪk ðæt, bʌt ðeɪ oʊbeɪd. ðeɪd bɪn wɔɹn ðɪs maɪt hæpən.

None of them seemed to like that, but they obeyed. They'd been warned this might happen.

feɪl kənteɪn əɹ nɝvəsnəs - ʃi dɪdn laɪk livɪŋ ði æʃəmən, ðɛɹ bɛs minz ʌv ɪskeɪp. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns ɪleɪn əndaʊɾɪdli hæd spaɪz ən ɡɑɹdz hɪɾən ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ɹɛɾi tə spɹɪŋ aʊt ʃəd mæɾɝz tɝn deɪnʒɝəs. feɪl wʊɾə laɪkt ə sɪməlɝ pɹətɛkʃən, bʌt bɹɪŋɪŋ ə meɪl tʃænlɝ ɪn tə spik wɪð ðə kwin . . . wɛl, ðɪs wɑz haʊ ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi.

Faile contained her nervousness - she didn't like leaving the Asha'man, their best means of escape. Particularly since Elayne undoubtedly had spies and Guards hidden inside the sitting room, ready to spring out should matters turn dangerous. Faile would have liked a similar protection, but bringing a male channeler in to speak with the Queen . . . well, this was how it would have to be.

ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ɪleɪnz doʊmeɪn.

They were in Elayne's domain.

feɪl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, dʒɔɪnɪŋ pɛɹɪn, æliændɝ ən mɔɹɡeɪs ɪn ðə smɔl saɪd ɹum. tʃɛɹz hæd bɪn ɝeɪnʒd; ɪleɪn hæd fɔɹsin ðɪs pɔz-sɪbɪlɪɾi. ðeɪ weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪleɪn tə ɛntɝ bɪfɔɹ sɪɾɪŋ. feɪl kʊdn si ɛni pleɪs fəɹ ɡɑɹdz tə bi haɪɾɪŋ.

Faile took a deep breath, joining Perrin, Alliandre and Morgase in the small side room. Chairs had been arranged; Elayne had foreseen this pos-sibility. They waited for Elayne to enter before sitting. Faile couldn't see any place for Guards to be hiding.

ɪleɪn ɛntɝɾ ən weɪvd ə hænd. ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ðə læmplaɪt.

Elayne entered and waved a hand. The Great Serpent ring on her finger glittered in the lamplight.

feɪl hæd nɪɹli fɝɡɑɾən ðət ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɝn ɛni ɡɑɹdzmɪn lɝkɪŋ ɝaʊn tə hɛlp ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl wɑz əz deɪnʒɝəs əz ə dʌzən soʊlʒɝz.

Faile had nearly forgotten that she was Aes Sedai. Perhaps there weren't any Guardsmen lurking around to help a woman who could channel was as dangerous as a dozen soldiers.

wɪtʃ ə ðə ɹumɝz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə fɑðɝ ʌv ɪleɪnz tʃaɪld wɝ tə bi bɪlivd? ʃʊɹli nɑt ðə wʌnz əbaʊt ðət ful ʌv ə mæn ɪn əɹ ɡɑɹd - ðət wɑz moʊs laɪkli ɑbfəskeɪʃən. kəɾ ɪt pɑsəbli bi ɹænd hɪmsɛlf?

Which of the rumors regarding the father of Elayne's child were to be believed? Surely not the ones about that fool of a man in her Guard - that was most likely obfuscation. Could it possibly be Rand himself?

mɔɹɡeɪs ɛntɝɾ æftɝ ɪleɪn. ʃi wɔɹ ə səbdud ɡaʊn ə dip ɹɛd. ʃi sæt daʊn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ dɔɾɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ kɛɹfəli, ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ saɪlənt.

Morgase entered after Elayne. She wore a subdued gown of deep red. She sat down beside her daughter, watching carefully, remaining silent.

"soʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ɪkspleɪn tə mi waɪ aɪ ʃʊdn dʒʌst ɛksəkjut jə boʊθ əz tʃɹeɪɾɝz."

"So," Elayne said, "explain to me why I shouldn't just execute you both as traitors."

feɪl blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. pɛɹɪn, haʊɛvɝ, snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɹænd wəd θɪŋk vɛɹi haɪli ʌv ðət muv."

Faile blinked in surprise. Perrin, however, snorted. "I don't think Rand would think very highly of that move."

"aɪm nɑt bɪhoʊldən tə hɪm," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ju ɪkspɛk mi tə bɪliv ðəɾ i wɑz bɪhaɪn jə sɪdusɪŋ maɪ sɪɾəzənz ən neɪmɪŋ jɝsɛlf ə kɪŋ?"

"I'm not beholden to him," Elayne said. "You expect me to believe that he was behind you seducing my citizens and naming yourself a king?"

"ju hæv ə fju ʌv jəɹ fæks bækwɝd, jəɹ mædʒəsti," feɪl sɛd tɛstəli. "pɛɹɪn nɛvɝ neɪm hɪmsɛlf kɪŋ."

"You have a few of your facts backward, Your Majesty," Faile said testily. "Perrin never named himself king."

"oʊ, ən dɪɾ i ɹeɪz ðə flæɡ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən, əz maɪ ɪnfɔɹməns tɛl mi hi dɪd?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"Oh, and did he raise the flag of Manetheren, as my informants tell me he did?" Elayne asked.

"aɪ dɪd ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ pʊɾ ɪɾ əweɪ ʌv maɪ oʊn tʃɔɪs."

"I did that," Perrin said. "But I put it away of my own choice."

"wɛl, ðæts sʌmθɪŋ," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ju meɪ nɑɾ əv kɔl jɝsɛlf ə kɪŋ, bʌt hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðət bænɝ wɑz ɪsɛnʃəli ðə seɪm θɪŋ. oʊ, sɪt daʊn, ɔl ə ju." ʃi weɪvd ə hænd. ə tʃɹeɪ lɪftəɾ ɔf ðə fɑɹ teɪbəl ən floʊɾəd oʊvɝ tə hɝ. ɪt bɔɹ ɡoʊbləts ən ə pɪtʃɝ ʌv waɪn, əz wɛl əz ə tipɑɾ ən kʌps.

"Well, that's something," Elayne replied. "You may not have called yourself a king, but holding up that banner was essentially the same thing. Oh, sit down, all of you." She waved a hand. A tray lifted off the far table and floated over to her. It bore goblets and a pitcher of wine, as well as a teapot and cups.

fɛtʃɪŋ ɪt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, feɪl θɔt. ɪts ə ɹimaɪndɝ ə hɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ. ə ɹæðɝ ənsʌɾəl wʌn.

Fetching it with the One Power, Faile thought. It's a reminder of her strength. A rather unsubtle one.

"stɪl," ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪ wɪl də ðə bɛs fəɹ maɪ ɹɛlm, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə kɑst."

"Still," Elayne said, "I will do the best for my realm, regardless of the cost."

"aɪ daʊt ðəɾ əpsɛɾɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," æliændɝ sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli, "wʊd bi bɛs fəɹ jəɹ ɹɛlm.

"I doubt that upsetting the Two Rivers," Alliandre said hesitantly, "would be best for your realm.

ɛksəkjuɾɪŋ ðɛɹ liɾɝ wəɾ əndaʊɾɪdli θɹoʊ ðə ɹidʒən ɪndə ɹɪbɛljən."

Executing their leader would undoubtedly throw the region into rebellion."

"soʊ fɑɹ əz aɪm kənsɝnd," ɪleɪn sɛd, pɔɹɪŋ sɛvɹəl kʌps ə ti, "ðeɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ɹɪbɛljən."

"So far as I'm concerned," Elayne said, pouring several cups of tea, "they're already in rebellion."

"wi keɪm tə jə pisfəli," feɪl sɛd. "hɑɹdli ði ækʃən ə ɹɛbəlz."

"We came to you peacefully," Faile said. "Hardly the action of rebels."

ɪleɪn tʊk ə sɪp ə ðə ti fɝst, əz wɑz ðə kʌstəm, tə pɹuv ɪt wɑzn pɔɪzənd. "maɪ ɛnvɔɪz tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əv bɪn ɹəfjuzd, ən jəɹ pipəl hɪɹ ɡeɪv mi ə mɛsədʒ - ən aɪ kwoʊt - 'ðə lænz ə lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldən-vɛs ɹɛfjus jəɹ ændɔɝən tæksəz. teɪʃɝ mæmbɝən!'"

Elayne took a sip of the tea first, as was the custom, to prove it wasn't poisoned. "My envoys to the Two Rivers have been refused, and your people here gave me a message - and I quote - 'The lands of Lord Perrin Golden-ves refuse your Andoran taxes. Tai'shar Mamtberen!'"

æliændɝ peɪld. pɛɹɪn ɡɹoʊn sɔfli, ə saʊn ðət keɪm aʊt feɪnli laɪk ə ɡɹaʊl. feɪl tʊk əɹ kʌp ən sɪpt əɹ ti - mɪnt, wɪð klaʊdbɛɹiz' ɪt wɑz ɡʊd. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk hæd plʌk, ðət wɑz sɝɾən.

Alliandre paled. Perrin groaned softly, a sound that came out faintly like a growl. Faile took her cup and sipped her tea - mint, with cloudberries' it was good. The Two Rivers folk had pluck, that was certain.

"ðiz ɑɹ pæʃənət taɪmz, jəɹ mædʒəsti," feɪl sɛd. "ʃʊɹli jə kən si ðət ðə pipəl maɪt bi kənsɝnd; ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əz nɑɾ ɔfən bɪn ə pɹaɪɔɹəɾi fəɹ jəɹ θɹoʊn."

"These are passionate times, Your Majesty," Faile said. "Surely you can see that the people might be concerned; the Two Rivers has not often been a priority for your throne."

"ðæts pʊɾɪŋ ɪt maɪldli," pɛɹɪn æɾəd wɪð ə snɔɹt. "moʊst ʌv əs ɡɹu ʌp nɑt noʊɪŋ wi wɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ. jə ɪɡnɔɹɾ ʌs."

"That's putting it mildly," Perrin added with a snort. "Most of us grew up not knowing we were part of Andor. You ignored us."

"ðæt wɑz kəz ði ɛɹiə wɑzn ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ɹɪbɛljən." ɪleɪn sɪpt əɹ ti.

"That was because the area wasn't rising in rebellion." Elayne sipped her tea.

"ɹɪbɛljən ɪzən ði oʊnli ɹizən mɛn maɪt nid ði ətɛnʃən ə ðə kwin u kleɪmz ðɛm,"

"Rebellion isn't the only reason men might need the attention of the queen who claims them,"

pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf juv hɝd, bʌt læs jɪɹ wi feɪs tʃɹɑləks ɑn əɹ oʊn, ən wɪθaʊɾ ə wɪskɝ ə hɛlp fɹəm ðə kɹaʊn. juɾ əv hɛlpt ɪf jud noʊn, bʌt ðə fæk ðət ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹups nɪɹbaɪ - nʌn keɪpəbəl ə noʊɪŋ əɹ deɪnʒɝ - sɛz sʌmθɪŋ."

Perrin said. "I don't know if you've heard, but last year we faced Trollocs on our own, and without a whisker of help from the Crown. You'd have helped if you'd known, but the fact that there were no troops nearby - none capable of knowing our danger - says something."

ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Elayne hesitated.

"ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əz ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd ɪts hɪstɝi," feɪl sɛd kɛɹfəli. "ɪt kʊdn ɹɛs fɝɛvɝ, nɑt wɪð tɑɹmən ɡdən lumɪŋ. nɑɾ æftɝ ʃɛltɝɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn dʊɹɪŋ ɪz tʃaɪldhʊd. pɑɹɾ ə mi wʌndɝz ɪf meɪnɛðɝən hæd tə fɔl, ɪf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz hæd tə ɹaɪz, tə pɹəvaɪɾ ə pleɪs fəɹ ɹænd ælθɹ tə bi ɹeɪzd. əmʌŋ fɑɹmɝz wɪð ðə blʌd - ən ɑbstənəsi - ʌv kɪŋz."

"The Two Rivers has rediscovered its history," Faile said carefully. "It couldn't rest forever, not with Tarmon Gai'don looming. Not after sheltering the Dragon Reborn during his childhood. Part of me wonders if Manetheren had to fall, if the Two Rivers had to rise, to provide a place for Rand al'Thor to be raised. Among farmers with the blood - and obstinacy - of kings."

"wɪtʃ meɪks ɪɾ ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðəɾ aɪ kwaɪət θɪŋz naʊ" ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ ɔfɝd jə ə bun soʊ ðət jə kəɾ æsk fəɹ fɝɡɪvnəs. aɪd pɑɹɾən ju, ən əl bi sɝɾən tə sɛn tʃɹups soʊ ðət jəɹ pipəl ɑɹ pɹətɛktəd. æksɛp ðɪs, ən wi kən ɔl ɡoʊ bæk tə laɪf ðə weɪ ɪt ʃəd bi."

"Which makes it all the more important that I quiet things now" Elayne said. "I offered you a boon so that you could ask for forgiveness. I'd pardon you, and I'll be certain to send troops so that your people are protected. Accept this, and we can all go back to life the way it should be."

"ðæɾ ɪzənt ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪl əv lɔɹdz, naʊ. aɪ fɔɾ ɪt fəɹ ə taɪm. jə meɪ, tu, bʌɾ ɪt woʊn tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ."

"That isn't going to happen," Perrin said softly. "The Two Rivers will have lords, now. I fought it for a time. You may, too, but it won't change anything."

'pɝhæps," ɪleɪn sɛd. "bʌt ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ jə wəd bi tə əɡɹi ðəɾ ə mæn kən dʒʌs kleɪm ə taɪɾəl wɪðɪn maɪ neɪʃən, ðən kip ɪt baɪ stʌbɝnli ɡæðɝɪŋ ən ɑɹmi. ɪt meɪks fəɹ ə tɛɹəbəl pɹɛsɪɾənt, pɛɹɪn. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə ɹilaɪz ðə pɹɪdɪkəmən juv pʊt mi ɪn."

'Perhaps," Elayne said. "But recognizing you would be to agree that a man can just claim a title within my nation, then keep it by stubbornly gathering an army. It makes for a terrible precedent, Perrin. I don't think you realize the predicament you've put me in."

"wil mʌɾəl θɹu," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪn ðət stʌbɝn toʊn i juzd wən i wɑznt ɡoʊɪŋ tə bʌdʒ.

"We'll muddle through," Perrin said in that stubborn tone he used when he wasn't going to budge.

"aɪm nɑt stɛpɪŋ daʊn."

"I'm not stepping down."

"jɔɹ duɪŋ ə pʊɹ dʒɑb ə pɝsweɪɾɪŋ mi jəl æksɛp maɪ ɔθɝ-aɪɾi," ɪleɪn snæpt.

"You're doing a poor job of persuading me you will accept my author-ity," Elayne snapped.

nɑt ɡʊd, feɪl θɔt, oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ tə dʒʌmp ɪn. ə klæʃ hɪɹ wəd nɑt sɝv əm wɛl.

Not good, Faile thought, opening her mouth to jump in. A clash here would not serve them well.

bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd spik, haʊɛvɝ, ənʌðɝ vɔɪs kʌɾ ɪn. "dɔt " mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd sɔfli, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ əɹ ti. "ɪf jə plæn tə dæns wɪð tɑvɝən, bi ʃʊɹ ðət jə noʊ ðə pɹɑpɝ stɛps. aɪv tʃɹævəld wɪð ðɪs mæn. aɪv sin ðə wɝl bɛn ɝaʊn hɪm; aɪv sin bɪɾɝ ɛnəmiz bɪkʌm ɪz ælaɪz tə faɪt ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf ɪz tə tʃɹaɪ tə muv ə maʊntən wɪð ə spun."

Before she could speak, however, another voice cut in. "Daughte " Morgase said softly, drinking her tea. "If you plan to dance with ta'veren, be sure that you know the proper steps. I've traveled with this man. I've seen the world bend around him; I've seen bitter enemies become his allies To fight the Pattern itself is to try to move a mountain with a spoon."

ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ mʌðɝ.

Elayne hesitated, looking at her mother.

"pliz fɝɡɪv mi ɪf aɪ oʊvɝstɛp maɪsɛlf," mɔɹɡeɪs kəntɪnjud. "bʌɾ ɪleɪn, aɪ pɹɑməs ðiz tu ðəɾ aɪ wəd spik fəɹ ðɛm. aɪ toʊl jə aɪ wʊd. ændɝ ɪz stʃɹɔŋ, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ɪt kəd bɹeɪk ɪtsɛlf əɡɛns ðɪs mæn. hi dʌz nɑt wɑn jəɹ θɹoʊn, aɪ pɹɑməs ɪt, ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz dʌz nid supɝvɪʒən.

"Please forgive me if I overstep myself," Morgase continued. "But Elayne, I promised these two that I would speak for them. I told you I would. Andor is strong, but I fear it could break itself against this man. He does not want your throne, I promise it, and the Two Rivers does need supervision.

wəɾ ɪt bi sətʃ ə tɛɹəbəl θɪŋ tə lɛɾ əm əv ðə mæn ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz əv tʃoʊzən?"

Would it be such a terrible thing to let them have the man they themselves have chosen?"

ðə smɔl ɹum fɛl saɪlənt. ɪleɪn aɪd pɛɹɪn, saɪzɪŋ ɪm ʌp. feɪl hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ.

The small room fell silent. Elayne eyed Perrin, sizing him up. Faile held her breath.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ əsum juv kʌm wɪð dɪmænz. lɛts hɪɹ əm soʊ wi kən dɪskʌvɝ ɪf ðɛɹz ɛniθɪŋ ðət kən bi dʌn."

"All right," Elayne said. "I assume you've come with demands. Let's hear them so we can discover if there's anything that can be done."

"noʊ dɪmænz," feɪl sɛd. "æn ɔfɝ."

"No demands," Faile said. "An offer."

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Elayne raised an eyebrow.

"jɔɹ mʌðɝ ɪz ɹaɪt," feɪl sɛd. "pɛɹɪn dʌz nɑt wɑn jəɹ θɹoʊn."

"Your mother is right," Faile said. "Perrin does not want your throne."

"wʌt jə tu wɑn meɪ bi ɪɹɛləvənt wʌns jəɹ pipəl ɡɛɾ ən aɪdiə ɪn ðɛɹ maɪnz."

"What you two want may be irrelevant once your people get an idea in their minds."

feɪl ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðeɪ lʌv hɪm, jəɹ mædʒəsti. ðeɪ ɹɪspɛk hɪm. ðəl də wʌɾ i sɛz.

Faile shook her head. "They love him, Your Majesty. They respect him. They'll do what he says.

wi kən ən wɪl pʊt daʊn aɪdiəz ə meɪnɛðɝən ɹaɪzɪŋ əɡɛn."

We can and will put down ideas of Manetheren rising again."

"ænd waɪ wəd jə də ðæt?" ɪleɪn æskt. "aɪ noʊ haʊ fæs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz ɹɛfjudʒiz kʌmɪŋ ɪn oʊvɝ ðə maʊntənz. neɪʃənz kəd ɹaɪz ən fɔl wɪð ðə kʌmɪŋ ə ðə læs bæɾəl. juv noʊ ɹizən tə ɡɪv ʌp ðə tʃæns tə fɔɹm jəɹ oʊn kɪŋdəm."

"And why would you do that?" Elayne asked. "I know how fast the Two Rivers is growing with those refugees coming in over the mountains. Nations could rise and fall with the coming of the Last Battle. You have no reason to give up the chance to form your own kingdom."

"æktʃəli ," feɪl sɛd, "wi hæv ɡʊd ɹizən. ændɝ ɪz ə stʃɹɔŋ neɪʃən, ən pɹɑspɝəs. ðə taʊnz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz meɪ bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹæpədli, bʌt ðə pipəl əv bɛɹli bɪɡʌn tə wɑn ə lɔɹd.

"Actually," Faile said, "we have good reason. Andor is a strong nation, and prosperous. The towns in the Two Rivers may be growing rapidly, but the people have barely begun to want a lord.

ðəɹ stɪl fɑɹmɝz ət hɑɹt. ðeɪ doʊnt wɑnt ɡlɔɹi; ðeɪ wɑn ðɛɹ kɹɑps tə sɝvaɪv." feɪl pɔzd.

They're still farmers at heart. They don't want glory; they want their crops to survive." Faile paused.

"pɝhæps jəɹ ɹaɪt, pɝhæps ðəɹ wɪl bi ənʌðɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ, bʌt ðæts oʊnli mɔɹ ɹizən tə hæv ælaɪz. noʊbɑdi wɑns sɪvəl wɔɹ ɪn ændɝ, list ʌv ɔl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk."

"Perhaps you're right, perhaps there will be another Breaking, but that's only more reason to have allies. Nobody wants civil war in Andor, least of all the Two Rivers folk."

"wʌt dʒju pɹəpoʊz, ðɛn?" ɪleɪn sɛd.

"What do you propose, then?" Elayne said.

"nʌθɪŋ, ɹɪli, ðət dʌzn ɪɡzɪst ɔlɹɛɾi," feɪl sɛd. "ɡɪv pɛɹɪn ən ɑfiʃəl taɪɾəl ən meɪk ɪm haɪ lɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz." "ænd wʌt dʒju min baɪ 'haɪ lɔɹd?" ɪleɪn æskt. "hid ɹæŋk haɪɝ ðən ʌðɝ noʊbəl haʊsəz ɪn ændɝ, bʌt bɪniθ ðə kwin."

"Nothing, really, that doesn't exist already," Faile said. "Give Perrin an oficial title and make him High Lord over the Two Rivers." "And what do you mean by 'High Lord?" Elayne asked. "He'd rank higher than other noble Houses in Andor, but beneath the Queen."

"aɪ daʊt ði ʌðɝz wəd laɪk ðæt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "wʌɾ ə tæksəz?"

"I doubt the others would like that," Elayne said. "What of taxes?"

"ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz ɪɡzɛmpt," feɪl sɛd. əz ɪleɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən saʊɝd, ʃi kəntɪnjud kwɪkli.

"The Two Rivers is exempt," Faile said. As Elayne's expression soured, she continued quickly.

"jɔɹ mædʒəsti, ðə θɹoʊn ɪɡnɔɹd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz fəɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz, nɑt pɹətɛktɪŋ əm fɹəm bændəts əɹ sɛndɪŋ wɝkɝz tə ɪmpɹuv ðɛɹ ɹoʊdz, nɑt ɡɪvɪŋ əm ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts əɹ dʒʌstəsəz."

"Your Majesty, the throne ignored the Two Rivers for generations, not protecting them from bandits or sending workers to improve their roads, not giving them anything in the way of magistrates or justices."

"ðeɪ dɪdnt niɾ ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ ɡʌvɝn ðɛmsɛlvz faɪn." ʃi lɛft ənsɛd ðət ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk wəd pɹɑbli hæv tɔst aʊt tæks kəlɛktɝz, mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts əɹ dʒʌstəsəz sɛn baɪ ðə kwin  - bʌt ʃi sim tə noʊ ɪt.

"They didn't need it," Elayne said. "They governed themselves fine." She left unsaid that the Two Rivers folk would probably have tossed out tax collectors, magistrates or justices sent by the Queen  - but she seemed to know it.

"wɛl," feɪl sɛd, "nʌθɪŋ nidz tʃeɪnʒ, ðɛn. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɡʌvɝnz ɪtsɛlf."

"Well," Faile said, "nothing needs change, then. The Two Rivers governs itself."

"ju kəɾ əv tɛɹəf-fɹi tʃɹeɪd wɪð ðɛm," æliændɝ sɛd.

"You could have tariff-free trade with them," Alliandre said.

"sʌmθɪŋ aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"Something I already have," Elayne said.

"soʊ nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒəz," feɪl sɛɾ əɡɛn. "ɪksɛp ðət jə ɡeɪn ə paʊɝfəl pɹɑvəns tə ðə wɛst.

"So nothing changes," Faile said again. "Except that you gain a powerful province to the west.

pɛɹɪn, əz jəɹ ælaɪ ən sʌbʒɪkt lɔɹd, wɪl əɡɹi tə mɑɹʃəl tʃɹups ɪn jəɹ dɪfɛns. hɪl ɔlsoʊ kɔl ʌp ɪz swɔɹn mɑnɑɹks tə jəɹ əlidʒəns."

Perrin, as your ally and subject lord, will agree to marshal troops in your defense. He will also call up his sworn monarchs to your allegiance."

Tear, Illian, and maybe now Arad Doman are beneath his rule. Nations join rather than split, these days. Andor looks smaller by the hour."

wɛl, ɪn feɪlz vju, æliændɝ hæd bɪn kɑɾ ʌp baɪ pɛɹɪn əz ə tɑvɝən. ðəɹ hædn bɪn mʌtʃ plænɪŋ. bʌɾ æliændɝ maɪt si ɪɾ ʌðɝwaɪz.

bɪznəs. ðɛɹəd nid tə bi ə weɪ ɝaʊn ɪt...

business. There'd need to be a way around it...

ðət ɡɪvz əs ə liɡəl ɪkskjus fəɹ jəɹ ɪɡzɛmpʃən. ʌv kɔɹs, pɛɹɪn wɪl əv əθɔɹəɾi tə dɪp ɪndə ðoʊz fʌnz tə ɪmpɹuv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɹoʊdz, fud stɔɹz, dɪfɛnsəz."

That gives us a legal excuse for your exemption. Of course, Perrin will have authority to dip into those funds to improve the Two Rivers. Roads, food stores, defenses."

ɪleɪn lʊkt ət feɪl, ðən smaɪld, teɪkɪŋ ə lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk ə ti. "aɪm bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə nɑt tə ɛksəkjut ju."

"ðæts sɝɾənli ə ɹɪlif," æliændɝ sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. əz ðə lis paʊɝfəl wʌn ɪn ðə junjən, ʃi stʊd tə ɡeɪn ə lɑt fɹəm ði əlaɪənsəz.

ʃiz æmɪɝlɪn, faɪnəli," ɪleɪn sɛd, əz ɪf ðə fæk hæd bɪn ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ðoʊ feɪl faʊn hɝsɛlf əmeɪzd. haʊ hæd ðət hæpənd, ən waɪ wɑzn pɛɹɪn sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ɪt?

She's Amyrlin, finally," Elayne said, as if the fact had been inevitable. Perrin nodded, though Faile found herself amazed. How had that happened, and why wasn't Perrin surprised by it?

"Do you know where he is currently?" Faile asked. Perrin had a good idea, from his visions, but she wanted to know what Elayne knew. "I don't know," Elayne said. "But I do know where he will be . . ."

fɔɹtwoʊnə æθeɪɪm dɛvi pɛndʒɹæɡ, ɹulɝ ə ðə ɡlɔɹiəs sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ mɑɹtʃt ɪndə hɝ titʃɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ. ʃi wɔɹ ə mæɡnɪfəsənt ɡaʊn ʌv ɡoʊldən klɔθ, kʌɾ æftɝ ðə haɪəst ɪmpɪɹiəl fæʃən. ðə skɝt splɪɾ ət ðə fɹʌn tə dʒʌst əbʌv ðə niz, ən wɑz soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ ɪt tʊk faɪv dækoʊvæl tə kæɹi ðə saɪdz ən tʃɹeɪn.

Fortuona Athaem Devi Paendrag, ruler of the Glorious Seanchan Empire marched into her Teaching Chamber. She wore a magnificent gown of golden cloth, cut after the highest Imperial fashion. The skirt split at the front to just above the knees, and was so long that it took five da'covale to carry the sides and train.

ʃi wɔɹ ən ɔɹneɪt hɛdʒɹɛs, ʌv ɡoʊld ən kɹɪmzən sɪlk wɪð bjuɾəfəl sɪlkən wɪŋz ʃeɪp laɪk ðoʊz ʌv ən aʊl teɪkɪŋ flaɪt, ən əɹ ɑɹmz ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð θɝtin bɹeɪslɪts, itʃ ʌv ə dɪfɹən dʒɛmstoʊn kɑmbəneɪʃən. ʃi wɔɹ kɹɪstəl əɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ ɪn ə lɔŋ stʃɹænd. ʃi hæd hɝɾ ən aʊl əbʌv əɹ wɪndoʊ ðə læs naɪt, ən ɪt hæd nɑt floʊn əweɪ wən ʃi lʊkt aʊt. ən oʊmən ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ɡɹeɪt kɛɹ ʃəd bi teɪkən, ðət ðə nɛks deɪz wəd bi wʌnz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾənt dɪsɪʒənz. ðə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɑns wɑz tə wɛɹ dʒuəlɹi wɪð paʊɝfəl sɪmbəlɪzəm.

She wore an ornate headdress, of gold and crimson silk with beautiful silken wings shaped like those of an owl taking flight, and her arms glittered with thirteen bracelets, each of a different gemstone combination. She wore crystal at her throat in a long strand. She had heard an owl above her window the last night, and it had not flown away when she looked out. An omen indicating great care should be taken, that the next days would be ones of important decisions. The proper response was to wear jewelry with powerful symbolism.

wən ʃi ɛntɝd ðə tʃeɪmbɝ, ðoʊz ɪnsaɪd pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz. oʊnli ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd -  mɛn ɪn ɑɹmɝ ə blʌd ɹɛɾ ən dip ɡɹin--wɑz ɪɡzɛmpt; ðeɪ baʊd, bʌt kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz ʌp, wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ deɪnʒɝ.

When she entered the chamber, those inside prostrated themselves. Only the Deathwatch Guard -  men in armor of blood red and deep green--was exempt; they bowed, but kept their eyes up, watching for danger.

ðə lɑɹdʒ tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz wɪndoʊləs. laɪnz ə stæk pɑɾɝi stʊɾ ət wʌn ɛnd, ə pleɪs fəɹ deɪmeɪn tə pɹæktəs wivz ə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. ðə flɔɹ wɑz kʌvɝɾ ɪn woʊvən mæts wɛɹ stʌbɝn deɪmeɪn wɝ sɛn tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹaɪðɪŋ ɪn peɪn. ɪt wəd nɑt də fəɹ əm tə bi hɑɹm fɪzɪkəli.

The large chamber was windowless. Lines of stacked pottery stood at one end, a place for damane to practice weaves of destruction. The floor was covered in woven mats where stubborn damane were sent to the ground, writhing in pain. It would not do for them to be harmed physically.

deɪmeɪn wɝ əmʌŋ ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt tulz ði ɛmpaɪɝ hæd, mɔɹ væljəbəl ðən hɔɹsəz əɹ ɹeɪkən.

Damane were among the most important tools the Empire had, more valuable than horses or raken.

jə dɪd nɑt dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə bis kəz ɪt wɑz sloʊ tə lɝn; jə pʌnɪʃt ɪɾ əntɪl ɪt lɝnd.

You did not destroy a beast because it was slow to learn; you punished it until it learned.

fɔɹtwoʊnə kɹɔs ðə tʃeɪmbɝ tə wɛɹ ə pɹɑpɝ ɪmpɪɹiəl θɹoʊn hæd bɪn sɛɾ ʌp. ʃi kɑmənli keɪm hɪɹ, tə wɑtʃ ðə deɪmeɪn biɪŋ wɝkt əɹ bɹoʊkən. ɪt suð hɝ. ðə θɹoʊn wɑz ətɑp ə smɔl deɪz; ʃi klaɪm ðə stɛps, tʃɹeɪn ɹʌslɪŋ əz əɹ dækoʊvæl kæɹiɾ ɪt. ʃi tɝn tə feɪs ðə ɹum, əlaʊɪŋ ðə sɝvəns tə ɝeɪnʒ əɹ dʒɹɛs. ðeɪ tʊk əɹ baɪ hɝ ɑɹmz ən lɪftəɾ əɹ bæk ɪndə ðə θɹoʊn, dʒɹeɪpɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ ɡoʊldən skɝts daʊn ðə fɹʌn ə ðə deɪz laɪk ə tæpəstʃɹi.

Fortuona crossed the chamber to where a proper Imperial Throne had been set up. She commonly came here, to watch the damane being worked or broken. It soothed her. The throne was atop a small dais; she climbed the steps, train rustling as her da'covale carried it. She turned to face the room, allowing the servants to arrange her dress. They took her by her arms and lifted her back into the throne, draping her long golden skirts down the front of the dais like a tapestry.

ðoʊz skɝts wɝ soʊn wɪð ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋz ʌv ɪmpɪɹiəl paʊɝ. ði ɛmpɹɛs ɪz sintʃæn. ði ɛmpɹɛs wɪl lɪv fɝɛvɝ. ði ɛmpɹɛs mʌs bi oʊbeɪd. ʃi sæɾ əz ə lɪvɪŋ bænɝ tə ðə maɪɾ ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ.

Those skirts were sewn with the writings of Imperial power. The Empress IS Seanchan. The Empress WILL live forever. The Empress MUST be obeyed. She sat as a living banner to the might of the Empire.

sɪlutʃə tʊk əɹ pəzɪʃən ɑn ðə loʊɝ stɛps ə ðə deɪz. ðɪs dʌn, ðə kɔɹɾiɝz ɹeɪz ðɛmsɛlvz. ðə deɪmeɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, ɹɪmeɪnd nilɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ tɛn ə ðɛm, wɪð hɛdz baʊd, ðɛɹ sʌldəm hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ liʃɪz ən - ɪn ə fju keɪsəz - pæɾɪŋ əm əfɛkʃənətli ɑn ðə hɛdz.

Selucia took her position on the lower steps of the dais. This done, the courtiers raised themselves. The damane, of course, remained kneeling. There were ten of them, with heads bowed, their sul'dam holding their leashes and - in a few cases - patting them affectionately on the heads.

kɪŋ bɛslən ɛntɝd. hid ʃeɪv moʊst ə hɪz hɛd, livɪŋ oʊnli ə dɑɹk stʃɹɪp ɑn ðə tɑp, ən sɛvən ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz hæd bɪn lækɝd. wʌn mɔɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪl ðən ɛniwʌn ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən, ɛksɛptɪŋ fɔɹtwoʊnə hɝsɛlf. hi stɪl wɔɹ ɔltɑɹən kloʊðɪŋ - ə junəfɔɹm ʌv ɡɹin ən waɪt -  ɹæðɝ ðən sintʃæn ɹoʊbz. ʃi hæd nɑt pɹɛst ɪm ɑn ðɪs.

King Beslan entered. He'd shaved most of his head, leaving only a dark strip on the top, and seven of his fingernails had been lacquered. One more fingernail than anyone on this side of the ocean, excepting Fortuona herself. He still wore Altaran clothing - a uniform of green and white -  rather than Seanchan robes. She had not pressed him on this.

soʊ fɑɹ əz ʃi nu, sɪns ɪz ɹeɪzɪŋ, bɛslən hædn meɪɾ ɛni plænz tə hæv əɹ əsæsəneɪɾəd.

So far as she knew, since his raising, Beslan hadn't made any plans to have her assassinated.

ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl. ɛni sintʃæn wəɾ əv ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡʌn skimɪŋ. səm wʊɾə tʃɹaɪɾ ən əsæsəneɪʃən; ʌðɝz wʊɾə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə meɪk oʊnli plænz, bʌt ɹɪmeɪn səpɔɹɾɪv. bʌɾ ɔl wʊɾə kənsɪɾɝd kɪlɪŋ hɝ.

Remarkable. Any Seanchan would have immediately begun scheming. Some would have tried an assassination; others would have decided to make only plans, but remain supportive. But all would have considered killing her.

mɛni ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən θɔt dɪfɹənli. ʃid nɛvɝ əv bɪlivd ɪt, ɪf nɑt fəɹ əɹ taɪm wɪð meɪtʃɹim. ðət wɑz ɑbviəsli wʌn ɹizən waɪ fɔɹtwoʊnə hæd bɪn ɹikwaɪɝd tə ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm. ʃi dʒʌst wɪʃt ʃiɾ ɪntɝpɹəɾəd ði oʊmənz ɝliɝ.

Many on this side of the ocean thought differently. She'd never have believed it, if not for her time with Matrim. That was obviously one reason why Fortuona had been required to go with him. She just wished she'd interpreted the omens earlier.

bɛslən wɑz dʒɔɪn baɪ kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl lunəl ɡælɡən ən ə fju mɛmbɝz ə ðə loʊ blʌd.

Beslan was joined by Captain-General Lunal Galgan and a few members of the low Blood.

ɡælɡən wɑz ə waɪd-ʃoʊldɝd fɛloʊ wɪð ə kɹɛst ʌv waɪt hɛɹ ətɑp ɪz hɛd. ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə blʌd dɪfɝd tə hɪm; ðeɪ nu hi hæɾ əɹ feɪvɝ. ɪf θɪŋz wɛnt wɛl hɪɹ ən wɪð ðə ɹɛkləmeɪʃən ə sintʃæn, ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡʊd tʃæns ʃid ɹeɪz ɪm tə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli. ðə ɹæŋks ə ðə fæmli wəd nid tə bi ɹifɪld, æftɝ ɔl, wʌns fɔɹtwoʊnə ɹɪtɝn ən ɹɪstɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ.

Galgan was a wide-shouldered fellow with a crest of white hair atop his head. The other members of the Blood deferred to him; they knew he had her favor. If things went well here and with the reclamation of Seanchan, there was a good chance she'd raise him to the Imperial family. The ranks of the family would need to be refilled, after all, once Fortuona returned and restored order.

əndaʊɾɪdli, mɛni hæd bɪn əsæsəneɪɾəd əɹ ɛksəkjuɾəd. ɡælɡən wɑz ə væljəbəl ælaɪ. hid nɑɾ oʊnli wɝkt oʊpənli əɡɛnst sjuɹɔθ, bʌt hæd sədʒɛstəd ði əsɔlt ɑn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɪtʃ hæd ɡɔn wɛl. ɪkstʃɹimli wɛl.

Undoubtedly, many had been assassinated or executed. Galgan was a valuable ally. He'd not only worked openly against Suroth, but had suggested the assault on the White Tower, which had gone well. Extremely well.

mɛlɪtin, fɔɹtwoʊnəz dɝsʌldəm, stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən baʊɾ əɡɛn. ðə staʊt, ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən lɛɾ ə deɪmeɪn wɪð dɑɹk bɹaʊn hɛɹ ən blʌdʃɑɾ aɪz. əpɛɹənli ðɪs wʌn wɛpt ɔfən.

Melitene, Fortuona's der'sul'dam, stepped forward and bowed again. The stout, graying woman led a damane with dark brown hair and bloodshot eyes. Apparently this one wept often.

mɛlɪtin hæd ðə pɹɛzəns tə lʊk ɪmbɛɹəst ət ðə wipɪŋ, ən baʊɾ ɛkstʃɹə loʊ. fɔɹtwoʊnə tʃoʊz nɑt tə noʊɾəs ðət ðə deɪmeɪn wɑz æktɪŋ soʊ dɪsplisɪŋli. ðɪs wʌn wɑz ə faɪn kætʃ, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ pɛtʃələns.

Melitene had the presence to look embarrassed at the weeping, and bowed extra low. Fortuona chose not to notice that the damane was acting so displeasingly. This one was a fine catch, despite her petulance.

fɔɹtwoʊnə meɪɾ ə sɪɹiz ə dʒɛstʃɝz tə sɪlutʃə, ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ əɹ ɪn wʌt tə seɪ. ðə wʊmən wɑtʃt wɪð kin aɪz, hæf ə hɝ hɛd kʌvɝɾ ɪn klɔθ waɪl ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə hɛɹ tə ɡɹoʊ ðɛɹ, ði ʌðɝ hæf ʃeɪvd, fɔɹtwoʊnə wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli hæv tə tʃuz ənʌðɝ vɔɪs, əz sɪlutʃə wɑz naʊ hɝ tʃɹuθspikɝ.

Fortuona made a series of gestures to Selucia, instructing her in what to say. The woman watched with keen eyes, half of her head covered in cloth while she waited for the hair to grow there, the other half shaved, Fortuona would eventually have to choose another Voice, as Selucia was now her Truthspeaker.

ʃoʊ əs wʌt ðɪs wʊmən kən du," sɪlutʃə sɛd, vɔɪsɪŋ ðə wɝdz fɔɹtwoʊnə hæd saɪn tə hɝ.

Show us what this woman can do," Selucia said, Voicing the words Fortuona had signed to her.

mɛlɪtin pæɾəd ðə deɪmeɪn ɑn ðə hɛd. "sʌfə wɪl ʃoʊ aɪ ɛmpɹɛs - meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ -  ðə paʊɝ ə slaɪsɪŋ ði ɛɹ."

Melitene patted the damane on the head. "Suffa will show I Empress - may she live forever -  the Power of slicing the air."

"pliz," sʌfə sɛd, lʊkɪŋ pliɾɪŋli təwɔɹd fɔɹtwoʊnə. "pliz, lɪsən tə mi. aɪm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit'.'

"Please," Suffa said, looking pleadingly toward Fortuona. "Please, listen to me. I am the Amyrlin Seat'.'

mɛlɪtin hɪst, ən sʌfəz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ɑbviəsli filɪŋ ə blæst ə peɪn θɹu ði æɾəm. ðə deɪmeɪn kəntɪnjuɾ ɛniweɪ. "aɪ kən ɔfɝ ɡɹeɪt baʊnti, paʊɝfəl ɛmpɹɛs! ɪf aɪm ɹɪtɝnd, əl ɡɪv jə tɛn wɪmən tə teɪk maɪ pleɪs. twɛnti! ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæz. aɪ__" ʃi bɹoʊk ɔf, moʊnɪŋ, ən kəlæps tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Melitene hissed, and Suffa's eyes opened wide, obviously feeling a blast of pain through the a'dam. The damane continued anyway. "I can offer great bounty, powerful Empress! If I am returned, I will give you ten women to take my place. Twenty! The most powerful the White Tower has. I__" She broke off, moaning, and collapsed to the ground.

mɛlɪtin wɑz swɛɾɪŋ. ʃi lʊk tə sɪlutʃə, spikɪŋ kwɪkli, nɝvəsli. "pliz ɪkspleɪn tə ði ɛmpɹɛs ʌv əs ɔl - meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ -  ðət maɪ aɪz ɑɹ loʊɝd fəɹ nɑt hævɪŋ tʃɹeɪn ðɪs wʌn pɹɑpɝli. sʌfə ɪz əmeɪzɪŋli stʌbɝn, dɪspaɪt haʊ kwɪk ʃiz tə wip ən ɔfɝ ʌðɝz ɪn əɹ pleɪs."

Melitene was sweating. She looked to Selucia, speaking quickly, nervously. "Please explain to the Empress of us all - may she live forever -  that my eyes are lowered for not having trained this one properly. Suffa is amazingly stubborn, despite how quick she is to weep and offer others in her place."

fɔɹtwoʊnə sæt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, lɛɾɪŋ mɛlɪtin swɛt. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi saɪn fəɹ sɪlutʃə tə spik.

Fortuona sat for a moment, letting Melitene sweat. Eventually, she signed for Selucia to speak.

"ði ɛmpɹɛs ɪz nɑt dɪsplizd wɪð ju," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. "ðiz mɛɹɑɾədəmeɪn u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ hæv ɔl pɹuvən stʌbɝn."

"The Empress is not displeased with you," Selucia Voiced. "These marattidamane who call themselves Aes Sedai have all proven stubborn."

"pliz ɪkspɹɛs maɪ ɡɹæɾətud tə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst wʌn," mɛlɪtin sɛd, ɹɪlæksɪŋ. "ɪf ɪt plizɪz ʃi huz aɪz lʊk ʌpwɝd, aɪ kən meɪk sʌfə pɝfɔɹm. bʌt ðəɹ meɪ bi fɝðɝ aʊtbɝsts."

"Please express my gratitude to the Greatest One," Melitene said, relaxing. "If it pleases She Whose Eyes Look Upward, I can make Suffa perform. But there may be further outbursts."

"ju meɪ kəntɪnju," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst.

"You may continue," Selucia Voiced.

mɛlɪtin nɛl bɪsaɪd sʌfə, spikɪŋ ʃɑɹpli ət fɝst, ðən kənsoʊlɪŋli. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi skɪld ət wɝkɪŋ wɪð fɔɹmɝ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, fɔɹtwoʊnə kənsɪɾɝd hɝsɛlf ɡʊd wɪð deɪmeɪn əz wɛl. ʃi ɛndʒɔɪd bɹeɪkɪŋ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn əz mʌtʃ əz əɹ bɹʌðɝ hæveɪt hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪd tʃɹeɪnɪŋ waɪld ɡɹoʊm. ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz faʊn ɪɾ ə pɪɾi ðəɾ i hæd bɪn əsæsəneɪɾəd. hi wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ə hɝ bɹʌðɝz u ʃiɾ ɛvɝ bɪn fɑn ʌv.

Melitene knelt beside Suffa, speaking sharply at first, then consolingly. She was very skilled at working with former marathdamane. Of course, Fortuona considered herself good with damane as well. She enjoyed breaking marath'damane as much as her brother Halvate had enjoyed training wild grolm. She'd always found it a pity that he had been assassinated. He was the only one of her brothers who she'd ever been fond of.

sʌfə faɪnəli ɡɑt bæk ɑntu hɝ niz. fɔɹtwoʊnə lin fɔɹwɝd, kjʊɹiəs. sʌfə baʊɾ əɹ hɛd, ən ə laɪn ə laɪt - bɹɪljən ən pjʊɹ - kʌt ði ɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ðət laɪn tɝn saɪdweɪz əlɔŋ ə sɛntʃɹəl æksəs, oʊpənɪŋ ə hoʊl dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə fɔɹtwoʊnəz θɹoʊn. tʃɹiz ɹʌsəl bɪɑnd, ən fɔɹtwoʊnəz bɹɛθ kɑɾ əz ʃi sɔ ə hɔk wɪð ə waɪt hɛd stʃɹik əweɪ fɹəm ðə pɔɹɾəl. ən oʊmən ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ. ðə nɔɹməli ənflæpəbəl sɪlutʃə ɡæspt, ðoʊ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz ət ðə pɔɹɾəl əɹ ði oʊmən, fɔɹtwoʊnə dɪd nɑt noʊ.

Suffa finally got back onto her knees. Fortuona leaned forward, curious. Suffa bowed her head, and a line of light - brilliant and pure - cut the air in front of her. That line turned sideways along a central axis, opening a hole directly in front of Fortuona's throne. Trees rustled beyond, and Fortuonas breath caught as she saw a hawk with a white head streak away from the portal. An omen of great power. The normally unflappable Selucia gasped, though whether it was at the portal or the omen, Fortuona did not know.

fɔɹtwoʊnə kʌvɝɾ əɹ oʊn sɝpɹaɪz. soʊ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. tʃɹævlɪŋ wɑzn ə mɪθ əɹ ə ɹumɝ. ɪt wɑz ɹil. ðɪs tʃeɪnʒd ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wɔɹ.

Fortuona covered her own surprise. So it was true. Traveling wasn't a myth or a rumor. It was real. This changed everything about the war.

bɛslən wɔk fɔɹwɝd, boʊɪŋ tə hɝ, lʊkɪŋ hɛzɪɾənt. ʃi weɪv fɑɾ ɪm ən ɡælɡən tə kʌm tə wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd si ðə fɔɹəst ɡleɪd θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ. bɛslən stɛɹd, maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

Beslan walked forward, bowing to her, looking hesitant. She waved fot him and Galgan to come to where they could see the forest glade through the opening. Beslan stared, mouth hanging open.

ɡælɡən klæspt ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hi wɑz ə kjʊɹiəs wʌn. hid mɛt wɪð əsæsənz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ən hæɾ ɪnkwaɪɝɾ əbaʊt ðə kɑs fəɹ hævɪŋ fɔɹtwoʊnə kɪld. ðɛn, hid hæɾ itʃ ə ðə mɛn u kwoʊɾəd ɪm ə pɹaɪs ɛksəkjuɾəd. ə vɛɹi sʌɾəl mənuvɝ - ɪt wɑz mɛn tə ʃoʊ ðət ʃi ʃəd kənsɪɾɝ ɪm ə θɹɛt, əz i wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə miɾɪŋ wɪð əsæsənz. haʊɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə vɪzəbəl saɪn ə lɔɪəlti. / fɑloʊ jə fəɹ naʊ, ðə muv sɛd, bʌɾ aɪm wɑtʃɪŋ, ən aɪm æmbɪʃəs.

Galgan clasped his hands behind his back. He was a curious one. He'd met with assassins in the city, and had inquired about the cost for having Fortuona killed. Then, he'd had each of the men who quoted him a price executed. A very subtle maneuver - it was meant to show that she should consider him a threat, as he was not afraid of meeting with assassins. However it was also a visible sign of loyalty. / follow you for now, the move said, but I am watching, and I am ambitious.

ɪn mɛni weɪz, hɪz kɛɹfəl mənuvɝɪŋ wɑz mɔɹ kʌmfɝɾɪŋ tə hɝ ðən bɛslənz əpɛɹənli ənweɪvɝɪŋ lɔɪəlti. ðə fɝst, ʃi kəɾ æntɪsəpeɪt. ðə sɛkənd . . . wɛl, ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt tə meɪk ʌv ɪt jɛt. wəd meɪtʃɹim bi ikwəli lɔɪəl? wʌt wəɾ ɪt bi laɪk, tə hæv ə pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz hum ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə plɑɾ əɡɛnst? ɪt simd ɔlmoʊst ə fæntəsi, ðə taɪp ə teɪl toʊl tə kɑmən tʃɪlʒɹən tə meɪk əm dʒɹim ʌv ən ɪmpɑsəbəl mɛɹɪdʒ.

In many ways, his careful maneuvering was more comforting to her than Beslan's apparently unwavering loyalty. The first, she could anticipate. The second . . . well, she wasn't certain what to make of it yet. Would Matrim be equally loyal? What would it be like, to have a Prince of the Ravens whom she did not have to plot against? It seemed almost a fantasy, the type of tale told to common children to make them dream of an impossible marriage.

"ðɪs ɪz ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl!" bɛslən sɛd. "ɡɹeɪɾəst wʌn, wɪð ðɪs əbɪləɾi . . ." hɪz steɪʃən meɪɾ ɪm wʌn ə ði oʊnli pipəl eɪbəl tə spik dɝɛkli tə hɝ.

"This is incredible!" Beslan said. "Greatest One, with this ability . . ." His station made him one of the only people able to speak directly to her.

"ði ɛmpɹɛs wɪʃɪz tə noʊ," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst, ɹiɾɪŋ fɔɹtwoʊnəz fɪŋɡɝz, "ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə kæptʃɝd mɛɹəθdəmeɪn spoʊk ə ðə wɛpən."

"The Empress wishes to know," Selucia Voiced, reading Fortuona's fingers, "if any of the captured marath'damane spoke of the weapon."

"tɛl ðə haɪəst ɛmpɹɛs - meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ - ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt," mɛlɪtin sɛd, saʊndɪŋ wɝid. "ænd, ɪf aɪ meɪ bi soʊ boʊld, aɪ bɪliv ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt laɪɪŋ. ɪt simz ðət ði ɪksploʊʒən aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɑz ən aɪsəleɪɾəd æksəɾənt - ðə ɹɪzʌlt ə səm ənnoʊn tɛɹæŋɡɹil, juzd ɪmpɹuɾəntli.

"Tell the highest Empress - may she live forever - that they did not," Melitene said, sounding worried. "And, if I may be so bold, I believe that they are not lying. It seems that the explosion outside the city was an isolated accident - the result of some unknown ter'angreal, used imprudently.

pɝhæps ðəɹ ɪz noʊ wɛpən."

Perhaps there is no weapon."

ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl. fɔɹtwoʊnə hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn tə daʊt ðə vəlɪɾəti ʌv ðoʊz ɹumɝz. ði ɪksploʊʒən hæd hæpən bɪfɔɹ fɔɹtwoʊnə hæɾ ɝaɪvd ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ðə dɪteɪlz wɝ kənfjuzɪŋ. pɝhæps ðɪs hæɾ ɔl bɪn ə plɔɪ baɪ sjuɹɔθ əɹ əɹ ɛnəmiz.

It was possible. Fortuona had already begun to doubt the validity of those rumors. The explosion had happened before Fortuona had arrived in Ebou Dar, and the details were confusing. Perhaps this had all been a ploy by Suroth or her enemies.

"kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. "ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst wʌn wɪʃɪz tə noʊ wʌt jə wəd də wɪð ə paʊɝ sətʃ əz ðɪs tʃɹævlɪŋ əbɪləɾi."

"Captain-General," Selucia Voiced. "The Greatest One wishes to know what you would do with a Power such as this Traveling ability."

"ðæt dɪpɛnz," ɡælɡən sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪts ɹeɪnʒ? haʊ lɑɹdʒ kən ʃi meɪk ɪt?

"That depends," Galgan said, rubbing his chin. "What is its range? How large can she make it?

kən ɔl deɪmeɪn də ðɪs? ɑɹ ðəɹ lɪmɪteɪʃənz ɑn wɛɹ ə hoʊl kən bi oʊpənd? ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst wʌn, əl spik wɪð ðə deɪmeɪn ən ɡɛt ðiz ænsɝz."

Can all damane do this? Are there limitations on where a hole can be opened? If it pleases the Greatest One, I will speak with the damane and get these answers."

'ɪt dʌz pliz ði ɛmpɹɛs," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst.

'It does please the Empress," Selucia Voiced.

"ðɪs ɪz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ," bɛslən sɛd. "ðeɪ kəɾ ətæk bɪhaɪn əɹ bæɾəl laɪnz. ðeɪ kəɾ oʊpən ə pɔɹɾəl laɪk ðɪs ɪndə ði ɛmpɹɛsəz oʊn tʃeɪmbɝz, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. wɪð ðɪs . . . ɛvɹiθɪŋ wi noʊ əbaʊt wɔɹ wɪl tʃeɪnʒ."

"This is troubling," Beslan said. "They could attack behind our battle lines. They could open a portal like this into the Empress's own chambers, may she live forever. With this . . . everything we know about war will change."

ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd ʃʌfəld - ə saɪn ʌv ɡɹeɪt dɪskʌmfɝt. oʊnli fɹɪk kɛɹid dɪd nɑt muv. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu hɑɹɾɝ. fɔɹtwoʊnə nu ðəɾ i wəd sun bi sədʒɛstɪŋ ə nu, ɹoʊ-teɪɾɪŋ loʊkeɪʃən ə hɝ slipɪŋ kɔɹɾɝz.

The members of the Deathwatch Guard shuffled - a sign of great discomfort. Only Furyk Karede did not move. If anything, his expression grew harder. Fortuona knew that he would soon be suggesting a new, ro-tating location of her sleeping quarters.

fɔɹtwoʊnə θɔt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðət ɹɛn ɪn ði ɛɹ. ðət ɹɛn ɪn ɹiæləɾi ɪtsɛlf. ðɛn, kɑntʃɹɛɹi tə tʃɹədɪʃən, ʃi stʊɾ ʌp ɑn əɹ deɪz. fɔɹtʃənətli, bɛslən wɑz ðɛɹ, wʌn ʃi kəɾ ædʒɹɛs dɝɛkli - ən lɛt ði ʌðɝz hɪɹ əɹ kəmænz.

Fortuona thought for a moment, staring at that rent in the air. That rent in reality itself. Then, contrary to tradition, she stood up on her dais. Fortunately, Beslan was there, one she could address directly - and let the others hear her commands.

"ɹɪpɔɹts seɪ," fɔɹtwoʊnə ənaʊnst, "ðæt ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɪn ðə pleɪs kɔl ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə ki tə ɹikæptʃɝɪŋ sintʃæn, ðə ki tə hoʊldɪŋ ðɪs lænd, ən ðə ki tə pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl sɝv ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn.

"Reports say," Fortuona announced, "that there are still hundreds of marath'damane in the place called the White Tower. They are the key to recapturing Seanchan, the key to holding this land, and the key to preparing for the Last Battle. The Dragon Reborn will serve the Crystal Throne.

"wi hæv bɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd wɪð ə weɪ tə stʃɹaɪk. lɛɾ ɪt bi sɛd tə ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ðəɾ i ʃəd ɡæðɝ ɪz faɪnəst soʊlʒɝz. aɪ wɑn itʃ ən ɛvɹi deɪmeɪn wi kəntʃɹoʊl tə bi bɹɔt bæk tə ðə sɪɾi. wɪl tʃɹeɪn əm ɪn ðɪs mɛθəɾ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ. ən ðən wɪl ɡoʊ, ɪn fɔɹs, tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

"We have been provided with a way to strike. Let it be said to the Captain-General that he should gather his finest soldiers. I want each and every damane we control to be brought back to the city. We will train them in this method of Traveling. And then we will go, in force, to the White Tower.

bɪfɔɹ, wi stʃɹʌk əm wɪð ə pɪnpɹɪk. naʊ, wɪl lɛɾ əm noʊ ðə fʊl weɪɾ ʌv əɹ sɔɹd.

Before, we struck them with a pinprick. Now, we will let them know the full weight of our sword.

ɔl ə ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn mʌs bi liʃt."

All of the marath'damane must be leashed."

ʃi sæt bæk daʊn, lɛɾɪŋ ðə ɹum fɔl stɪl. ɪt wɑz ɹɛɹ ðət ði ɛmpɹɛs meɪd sətʃ ənaʊnsməns pɝsənəli. bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə taɪm fəɹ boʊlnəs.

She sat back down, letting the room fall still. It was rare that the Empress made such announcements personally. But this was a time for boldness.

"ju ʃəd nɑɾ əlaʊ wɝɾ ə ðɪs tə spɹɛd," sɪlutʃə sɛd tə hɝ, vɔɪs fɝm. ʃi wɑz naʊ spikɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɹoʊl əz tʃɹuθspikɝ. jɛs, ənʌðɝ wəɾ əv tə bi tʃoʊzən tə bi fɔɹtwoʊnəz vɔɪs.

"You should not allow word of this to spread," Selucia said to her, voice firm. She was now speaking in her role as Truthspeaker. Yes, another would have to be chosen to be Fortuona's voice.

"ju wəd bi ə ful tə lɛt ði ɛnəmi noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən wɪv ðɪs tʃɹævlɪŋ."

"You would be a fool to let the enemy know for certain we have this Traveling."

fɔɹtwoʊnə tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. jɛs, ðət wɑz tʃɹu. ʃi wəd meɪk sɝɾən itʃ ɪn ðɪs ɹum wɑz hɛl tə sikɹəsi. bʌt wʌns ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz kæptʃɝd, ðeɪ wəd tɔk ə hɝ pɹɑkləmeɪʃən, ən wəd ɹɛd ði oʊmənz ə hɝ vɪktɝi əpɑn ðə skaɪz ən wɝld ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Fortuona took a deep breath. Yes, that was true. She would make certain each in this room was held to secrecy. But once the White Tower was captured, they would talk of her proclamation, and would read the omens of her victory upon the skies and world around them.

wɪl nid tə stʃɹaɪk sun, sɪlutʃə saɪnd.

We will need to strike soon, Selucia signed.

jɛs, fɔɹtwoʊnə saɪn bæk. əɹ pɹiviəs ətæk wɪl əv əm ɡæðɝɪŋ ɑɹmz.

Yes, Fortuona signed back. Our previous attack will have them gathering arms.

əɹ nɛks muv wɪl əv tə bi dɪsaɪsɪv, ðɛn, sɪlutʃə saɪnd. bʌt θɪŋk. dɪlɪvɝɪŋ θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz ɪndə ðə waɪt taʊɝ θɹu ə hɪɾən beɪsmənt, ɹum. stʃɹaɪkɪŋ wɪð ðə fɔɹs ʌv ə θaʊzən hæmɝz əɡɛnst ə θaʊzən ænvəlz!

Our next move will have to be decisive, then, Selucia signed. But think. Delivering thousands of soldiers into the White Tower through a hidden basement, room. Striking with the force of a thousand hammers against a thousand anvils!

fɔɹtwoʊnə nɑɾəd.

Fortuona nodded.

ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz dumd.

The White Tower was doomed.

"doʊnt noʊ ðət ðɛɹz mʌtʃ mɔɹ tə seɪ, pɛɹɪn," θɔɹn sɛd, linɪŋ bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, təbæk smoʊk kɝlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz lɔŋ-stɛm paɪp. ɪt wɑz ə wɔɹm naɪt, ən ðeɪ dɪdn əv ə faɪɝ ɪn ðə hɑɹθ. dʒʌst ə fju kændəlz ɑn ðə teɪbəl, wɪð səm bɹɛd, tʃizɪz ən ə pɪtʃɝ ʌv eɪl.

"Don't know that there's much more to say, Perrin," Thorn said, leaning back in his chair, tabac smoke curling out of his long-stemmed pipe. It was a warm night, and they didn't have a fire in the hearth. Just a few candles on the table, with some bread, cheeses and a pitcher of ale.

pɛɹɪn pʌft ɑn ɪz oʊn paɪp. oʊnli hi, θɔɹn ən mæt wɝ ɪn ðə ɹum. ɡɔl ən ɡɹeɪɾi weɪɾəd aʊɾ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum. mæt hæd kɝs pɛɹɪn fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ ðoʊz tu - ən il ən ən æʃəmən wɝ ɹæðɝ kənspɪkjuəs. bʌt pɛɹɪn fɛl seɪfɝ wɪð ðoʊz tu ðən wɪð ən ɪntaɪɝ kʌmpəni ʌv soʊlʒɝz.

Perrin puffed on his own pipe. Only he, Thorn and Mat were in the room. Gaul and Grady waited out in the common room. Mat had cursed Perrin for bringing those two - an Aiel and an Asha'man were rather conspicuous. But Perrin felt safer with those two than with an entire company of soldiers.

hid ʃɛɹɾ ɪz stɔɹi wɪð mæt ən θɔɹn fɝst, spikɪŋ ə meɪɾən, ðə pɹɑfət, æliændɝ, ən ɡɑləd. ðən ðeɪ hæd fɪld ɪm ɪn ɑn ðɛɹ ɪkspɪɹiənsɪz. ɪt stʌn pɛɹɪn, haʊ mʌtʃ hæd hæpən tə ðə θɹi ʌv əm sɪns ðɛɹ pɑɹɾɪŋ.

He'd shared his story with Mat and Thorn first, speaking of Maiden, the Prophet, Alliandre, and Galad. Then they had filled him in on their experiences. It stunned Perrin, how much had happened to the three of them since their parting.

"ɛmpɹɛs ə ðə sintʃæn, ɛ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə smoʊk twɪst əbʌv ɪm ɪn ðə dɪm ɹum.

"Empress of the Seanchan, eh?" Perrin said, watching the smoke twist above him in the dim room.

"dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz," mæt sɛd. "ɪts dɪfɹənt."

"Daughter of the Nine Moons," Mat said. "It's different."

"æn jəɹ mɛɹid." pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪnd. "meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. mɛɹid."

"And you're married." Perrin grinned. "Matrim Cauthon. Married."

"ju dɪdn əv tə ʃɛɹ ðət pɑɹt, jə noʊ," mæt sɛd tə tɑm.

"You didn't have to share that part, you know," Mat said to Thom.

"oʊ, aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, aɪ dɪɾ ɪndid."

"Oh, I assure you, I did indeed."

"fɔɹ ə ɡlimən, jə sim tə liv aʊt moʊst ə ðə hɪɹoʊɪk pɑɹts ə ðə θɪŋz aɪ du," mæt sɛd. "æt lis jə mɛnʃən ðə hæt."

"For a gleeman, you seem to leave out most of the heroic parts of the things I do," Mat said. "At least you mentioned the hat."

pɛɹɪn smaɪld, kəntɛntəd. hi hædn ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ hid mɪst sɪɾɪŋ wɪð fɹɛnz tə spɛn ði ivnɪŋ tʃæɾɪŋ. ə kɑɹvd wʊɾən saɪn hʌŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊ, dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɪð ɹeɪnwɔɾɝ. ɪt dɪpɪktəd feɪsəz wɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ hæts ən ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd smaɪlz. ðə hæpi θɹɔŋ. ðəɹ wɑz pɹɑbli ə stɔɹi bɪhaɪn ðə neɪm.

Perrin smiled, contented. He hadn't realized how much he'd missed sitting with friends to spend the evening chatting. A carved wooden sign hung outside the window, dripping with rainwater. It depicted faces wearing strange hats and exaggerated smiles. The Happy Throng. There was probably a story behind the name.

ðə θɹi ʌv əm wɝ ɪn ə pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ, peɪd fəɹ baɪ mæt. ðeɪd bɹɔɾ ɪn θɹi ʌv ði ɪnz lɑɹdʒ hɑɹθ tʃɛɹz. ðeɪ dɪdn fɪt ðə teɪbəl, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ kʌmftəɹbəl. mæt lin bæk, pʊɾɪŋ ɪz fiɾ ʌp ɑn ðə teɪbəl. hi tʊk ʌp ə hʌŋk ʌv uz mɪlk tʃiz ən bɪɾ ɔf ə pis, ðən bæləns ðə ɹɛst ɑn ɪz tʃɛɹ ɑɹm.

The three of them were in a private dining chamber, paid for by Mat. They'd brought in three of the inn's large hearth chairs. They didn't fit the table, but they were comfortable. Mat leaned back, putting his feet up on the table. He took up a hunk of ewe's milk cheese and bit off a piece, then balanced the rest on his chair arm.

"ju noʊ, mæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "jɔɹ waɪf ɪz pɹɑbli gɑnə ɪkspɛk jə tə bi tɔt teɪbəl mænɝz."

"You know, Mat," Perrin said, "your wife is probably going to expect you to be taught table manners."

"oʊ, aɪv bɪn tɔt," mæt sɛd. "aɪ dʒʌs nɛvɝ lɝnd."

"Oh, I've been taught," Mat said. "I just never learned."

"aɪd laɪk tə mit hɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I'd like to meet her," Perrin said.

"ʃiz sʌmθɪŋ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," tɑm ɹɪplaɪd.

"She's something interesting," Thom replied.

"ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," mæt sɛd. "jæ." hi lʊkt wɪsfəl. "ɛniweɪ, juv hɝd ðə lɑɾ ʌv ɪt naʊ, pɛɹɪn. ðət blʌɾi bɹaʊn bɹɔɾ əs hɪɹ. hævən sin əɹ ɪn oʊvɝ tu wiks, naʊ."

"Interesting," Mat said. "Yeah." He looked wistful. "Anyway, you've heard the lot of it now, Perrin. That bloody Brown brought us here. Haven't seen her in over two weeks, now."

"kæn aɪ si ðə noʊt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Can I see the note?" Perrin asked.

mæt pæɾəd ə fju pɑkəts, ðən fɪʃt aʊɾ ə smɔl waɪt pis ə peɪpɝ, foʊldəd kloʊzd ən sild wɪð ɹɛd wæks. hi tɔst ɪɾ ɑntu ðə teɪbəl. ðə kɔɹnɝz wɝ bɛnt, ðə peɪpɝ smʌdʒd, bʌɾ ɪt hædn bɪn oʊpənd. meɪtʃɹim kɔθən wɑz ə mæn ə hɪz wɝd, ət list wən jə kəd pɹaɪ ən oʊθ aʊɾ ə hɪm.

Mat patted a few pockets, then fished out a small white piece of paper, folded closed and sealed with red wax. He tossed it onto the table. The corners were bent, the paper smudged, but it hadn't been opened. Matrim Cauthon was a man of his word, at least when you could pry an oath out of him.

pɛɹɪn lɪftəd ðə noʊt. ɪt smɛl feɪnli ʌv pɝfjum. hi tɝn ɪɾ oʊvɝ, ðən hɛld ɪɾ ʌp tə ə kændəl.

Perrin lifted the note. It smelled faintly of perfume. He turned it over, then held it up to a candle.

"dʌznt wɝk," mæt sɛd.

"Doesn't work," Mat said.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. "soʊ wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ɪt sɛz?"

Perrin grunted. "So what do you think it says?"

"doʊnt noʊ," mæt sɛd. "blʌɾi ɪnseɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ min, ðəɹ ɔl ɑd. bʌt vɛɹɪnz fɔlən kəmplitli ɔf əɹ stoʊn. doʊn səpoʊz juv hɝd fɹəm hɝ?"

"Don't know," Mat said. "Bloody insane Aes Sedai. I mean, they're all odd. But Verin's fallen completely off her stone. Don't suppose you've heard from her?"

"aɪ hævənt."

"I haven't."

"hoʊp ʃiz ɔl ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd. "ʃi saʊndəd wɝid sʌmθɪŋ maɪt hæpən tə hɝ." hi tʊk ðə noʊt bæk, ðən tæpt ɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl.

"Hope she's all right," Mat said. "She sounded worried something might happen to her." He took the note back, then tapped it on the table.

"ju gɑnə oʊpən ɪt?"

"You going to open it?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪl oʊpən ɪt wən aɪ ɡɛt bæk. aɪ - "

Mat shook his head. "I'll open it when I get back. I - "

ə nɑk keɪm ət ðə dɔɹ, ðən ɪt kɹikt oʊpən, ɹɪvilɪŋ ði ɪnkipɝ, ə jʌŋɡɝ mæn neɪm dɛnizəl. hi wɑz tɔl, wɪð ə lin feɪs ən ə hɛɾ i kɛpt ʃeɪvd. ðə mæn wɑz ɔl bʌt dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, fɹəm wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd sin, ivən ɡoʊɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ əz tə hæv ə pɔɹtʃɹəɾ ə ɹænd kəmɪʃən ən hʌŋ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum. ɪt wɑzn ə bæd laɪknəs.

A knock came at the door, then it creaked open, revealing the innkeeper, a younger man named Denezel. He was tall, with a lean face and a head he kept shaved. The man was all but Dragonsworn, from what Perrin had seen, even going so far as to have a portrait of Rand commissioned and hung in the common room. It wasn't a bad likeness.

"aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz, mæstɝ kɹɪmzən," dɛnizəl sɛd, "bʌt mæstɝ ɡoʊldənz mæn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn spikɪŋ wɪð hɪm."

"I apologize, Master Crimson," Denezel said, "but Master Goldens man insisted on speaking with him."

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"It's all right," Perrin said.

ɡɹeɪɾi poʊkt ɪz wɛðɝd feɪs ɪndə ðə ɹum ən dɛnizəl ɹitʃɹiɾəd.

Grady poked his weathered face into the room and Denezel retreated.

"hoʊ, ɡɹeɪɾi," mæt sɛd, weɪvɪŋ. "bloʊn ʌp ɛniwʌn ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ leɪtli?"

"Ho, Grady," Mat said, waving. "Blown up anyone interesting lately?"

ðə tæn æʃəmən fɹaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ tə pɛɹɪn. "maɪ lɔɹd. leɪɾi feɪl æsk mi tə ɹimaɪn jə wən mɪdnaɪɾ ɝaɪvd."

The tanned Asha'man frowned, looking to Perrin. "My Lord. Lady Faile asked me to remind you when midnight arrived."

mæt wɪsəld. "si, ðɪs ɪz waɪ aɪ lɛf maɪ waɪf ɪn ənʌðɝ kɪŋdəm."

Mat whistled. "See, this is why I left my wife in another kingdom."

ɡɹeɪɾiz fɹaʊn dipənd.

Grady's frown deepened.

"θæŋk ju, ɡɹeɪɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə saɪ. "aɪ hædn ɹilaɪz ðə taɪm. wɪl bi ɡoʊɪŋ sun."

"Thank you, Grady," Perrin said with a sigh. "I hadn't realized the time. We'll be going soon."

ði æʃəmən nɑɾəd, ðən wɪθdʒɹu.

The Asha'man nodded, then withdrew.

"bɝn hɪm," mæt sɛd. "kæn ðə mæn ət list smaɪl? fleɪmɪŋ skaɪ ɪz dɪpɹɛsɪŋ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt pipəl laɪk ɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪməteɪɾ ɪt."

"Burn him," Mat said. "Can't the man at least smile? Flaming sky is depressing enough without people like him trying to imitate it."

"wɛl, sʌn," θɔɹn sɛd, pɔɹɪŋ səm eɪl, "sʌm dʒʌs doʊn faɪn ðə wɝl pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli hjumɝəs leɪtli."

"Well, son," Thorn said, pouring some ale, "some just don't find the world particularly humorous lately."

"nɑnsɛns," mæt sɛd. "ðə wɝlz plɛnti hjumɝəs. ðə hoʊl blʌɾi pleɪs əz bɪn læfɪŋ ət mi, leɪtli. aɪm tɛlɪŋ ju, pɛɹɪn. wɪð ðoʊz dʒɹɔɪŋz ʌv əs əbaʊt, jə nid tə kip jəɹ hɛd loʊ."

"Nonsense," Mat said. "The world's plenty humorous. The whole bloody place has been laughing at me, lately. I'm telling you, Perrin. With those drawings of us about, you need to keep your head low."

"aɪ doʊn si haʊ aɪ kæn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪv ɡɑɾ ən ɑɹmi tə lid, pipəl tə kɛɹ fɔɹ."

"I don't see how I can," Perrin said. "I've got an army to lead, people to care for."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jəɹ teɪkɪŋ vɛɹɪnz wɔɹnɪŋ sɪɹiəsli ɪnʌf, læd," tɑm sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd.

"I don't think you're taking Verin's warning seriously enough, lad," Thom said, shaking his head.

"ju ɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðə bænəθ pipəl?"

"You ever heard of the Banath people?"

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət mæt.

"No," Perrin said, looking at Mat.

"ðeɪ wɝ ə ɡɹup ə sævədʒəz u ɹoʊmd wʌɾ ɪz naʊ ɑlməθ pleɪn," θɔɹn sɛd. "aɪ noʊ ə kʌpəl faɪn sɔŋz əbaʊt ðɛm. si, ðɛɹ vɛɹiəs tʃɹaɪbz ɔlweɪz peɪntəd ðə skɪn ə ðɛɹ liɾɝ ɹɛd tə meɪk ɪm stæn aʊt."

"They were a group of savages who roamed what is now Almoth Plain," Thorn said. "I know a couple fine songs about them. See, their various tribes always painted the skin of their leader red to make him stand out."

mæt tʊk ənʌðɝ baɪɾ ə hɪz tʃiz. "blʌɾi fulz. peɪntəd ðɛɹ liɾɝ ɹɛd? ðət wəd meɪk ɪm ə tɑɹɡət fəɹ ɛvɹi soʊlʒɝ ɑn ðə fild!"

Mat took another bite of his cheese. "Bloody fools. Painted their leader red? That would make him a target for every soldier on the field!"

"ðæt wɑz ðə pɔɪnt," θɔɹn sɛd. "ɪt wɑz ə tʃælənʒ, jə si. haʊ ɛls wəd ðɛɹ ɛnəmiz bi eɪbəl faɪn ɪm ən tɛs ðɛɹ skɪl əɡɛns hɪm?"

"That was the point," Thorn said. "It was a challenge, you see. How else would their enemies be able find him and test their skill against him?"

mæt snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪɾ əv peɪntəɾ ə fju dəkɔɪ soʊlʒɝz ɹɛd tə dɪstʃɹækt əm fɹəm mi, ðən hæd maɪ ɑɹtʃɝz fɛðɝ ðɛɹ liɾɝ wɪð æɹoʊz waɪl ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hʌn daʊn ðə fɛloʊz ðeɪ θɔt wɝ liɾɪŋ maɪ ɑɹmi."

Mat snorted. "I'd have painted a few decoy soldiers red to distract them from me, then had my archers feather their leader with arrows while everyone was trying to hunt down the fellows they thought were leading my army."

"æktʃəli ," tɑm sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə sɪp ə hɪz eɪl, "ðæts ɪɡzækli wʌt vɪl-liəm blʌdlɛɾɝ dɪd dʊɹɪŋ ɪz fɝst, ən læst, bæɾəl wɪð ðɛm. 'ðə sɔŋ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd deɪz' tɔks əbaʊɾ ɪt. bɹɪljən mənuvɝ.

"Actually," Thom said, taking a sip of his ale, "that's exactly what Vil-liam Bloodletter did during his first, and last, battle with them. 'The Song of a Hundred Days' talks about it. Brilliant maneuver.

aɪm sɝpɹaɪz juv hɝɾ ə ðət sɔŋ - ɪts vɛɹi əbskjʊɹ, ən ðə bæɾəl hæpən soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, moʊs hɪstɝi bʊks doʊn ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt."

I'm surprised you've heard of that song - it's very obscure, and the battle happened so long ago, most history books don't even remember it."

fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðə kɑmɛn meɪd mæt smɛl nɝvəs.

For some reason, the comment made Mat smell nervous.

"jɔɹ seɪɪŋ ðət wɝ meɪkɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz tɑɹɡəts," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"You're saying that we're making ourselves targets," Perrin said.

"aɪm seɪɪŋ," tɑm ɹɪplaɪd, "ðæt jə bɔɪz ɑɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ ən hɑɹɾɝ tə haɪd. ɛvɹiwɛɹ jə ɡoʊ, bænɝz pɹoʊkleɪm jəɹ ɝaɪvəl. pipəl tɔk əbaʊt ju. aɪm hæf-kənvɪns juv oʊnli sɝvaɪv ðɪs lɔŋ kəz ðə fɔɹseɪkən dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ tə faɪn ju."

"I'm saying," Thom replied, "that you boys are getting harder and harder to hide. Everywhere you go, banners proclaim your arrival. People talk about you. I'm half-convinced you have only survived this long because the Forsaken didn't know where to find you."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹæp ɪz ɑɹmi hæd nɪɹli fɔlən ɪntu. əsæsənz ɪn ðə naɪt wəd kʌm. "soʊ wʌt ʃəɾ aɪ du?"

Perrin nodded, thinking of the trap his army had nearly fallen into. Assassins in the night would come. "So what should I do?"

"mæts bɪn slipɪŋ ɪn ə dɪfɹən tɛn itʃ naɪt," tɑm sɛd. "æn səmtaɪmz ɪn ðə sɪɾi. jə ʃəd tʃɹaɪ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt. ɡɹeɪɾi kən meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz, ɹaɪt? waɪ nɑɾ əv ɪm meɪk wʌn fəɹ jə ɪndə ðə mɪɾəl ə jəɹ tɛn itʃ naɪt? snik aʊɾ ən slip sʌmpleɪs ɛls, ðən tʃɹævəl bæk ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ɛvɹiwʌn wɪl əsum jəɹ ɪn jəɹ tɛnt. ɪf əsæsənz stʃɹaɪk, jə woʊn bi ðɛɹ."

"Mat's been sleeping in a different tent each night," Thom said. "And sometimes in the city. You should try something like that. Grady can make gateways, right? Why not have him make one for you into the middle of your tent each night? Sneak out and sleep someplace else, then Travel back in the morning. Everyone will assume you're in your tent. If assassins strike, you won't be there."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. "ivən bɛɾɝ, aɪ kəd liv faɪv əɹ sɪks il ɪnsaɪd, ɑn əlɝt, weɪɾɪŋ."

Perrin nodded thoughtfully. "Even better, I could leave five or six Aiel inside, on alert, waiting."

"pɛɹɪn," mæt sɛd, "ðæts daʊnɹaɪt diviəs." hi smaɪld. "juv tʃeɪnʒd fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ, maɪ fɹɛnd."

"Perrin," Mat said, "that's downright devious." He smiled. "You've changed for the better, my friend."

'fɹʌm ju, əl tʃɹaɪ tə æksɛp ðəɾ əz ə kɑmpləmənt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi pɔzd, ðən æɾəd, "ɪt wɪl bi dɪfəkəlt."

'From you, I'll try to accept that as a compliment," Perrin said. He Paused, then added, "It will be difficult."

tɑm tʃʌkəld. "hiz ɹaɪt, ðoʊ. juv tʃeɪnʒd. wʌt hæpən tə ðə sɑft-spoʊkən, ənʃʊɹ bɔɪ aɪ hɛlpt ɪskeɪp ðə tu ɹɪvɝz?"

Thom chuckled. "He's right, though. You've changed. What happened to the soft-spoken, unsure boy I helped escape the Two Rivers?"

"hi pæs θɹu ðə blæksmɪθs faɪɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli.

"He passed through the blacksmith's fire," Perrin said softly.

θɔɹn nɑɾəd, simɪŋ tə ʌndɝstænd.

Thorn nodded, seeming to understand.

"æn ju, mæt?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "kæn aɪ də sʌmθɪŋ tə hɛlp ju? meɪbi lɛt jə tʃɹævəl bɪtwin tɛns?"

"And you, Mat?" Perrin said. "Can I do something to help you? Maybe let you Travel between tents?"

"noʊ. əl bi faɪn."

"No. I'll be fine."

"haʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə pɹətɛk jɝsɛlf?"

"How are you going to protect yourself?"

"wɪð maɪ wɪts."

"With my wits."

"plænɪŋ tə faɪn səm ə ðoʊz, ðɛn?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "əbaʊt taɪm."

"Planning to find some of those, then?" Perrin said. "About time."

mæt snɔɹɾɪd. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ən maɪ wɪts leɪtli? əl bi faɪn tʃɹʌs mi. ɹimaɪn mi tə tɛl jə əbaʊt ðə naɪt wən aɪ fɝs fɪɡjɝɾ aʊɾ aɪ kəd wɪn wʌtɛvɝ daɪs ɡeɪm aɪ wɑntəd tə. ɪts ə ɡʊd stɔɹi. ɪnvɑlvz fɔlɪŋ ɔf bɹɪdʒəz. wʌn bɹɪdʒ, ət list."

Mat snorted. "What is it with everyone and my wits lately? I'll be fine trust me. Remind me to tell you about the night when I first figured out I could win whatever dice game I wanted to. It's a good story. Involves falling off bridges. One bridge, at least."

"wɛl . . . jə kəd tɛl əs naʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Well . . . you could tell us now," Perrin said.

"nɑt ðə ɹaɪt taɪm. ɛniweɪ, ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ. si, aɪm livɪŋ sun."

"Not the right time. Anyway, it doesn't matter. See, I'm leaving soon."

θɔɹn smɛld ɪksaɪɾəd.

Thorn smelled excited.

"pɛɹɪn, jəl lɛn əs ə ɡeɪtweɪ, woʊn ju?" mæt æskt. "heɪt tə liv ðə bænd. ðəl bi ɪnkənsələbəl wɪθaʊt mi. ət lis ðeɪv ðoʊz dʒɹæɡənz tə bloʊ θɪŋz ʌp."

"Perrin, you will lend us a gateway, won't you?" Mat asked. "Hate to leave the Band. They'll be inconsolable without me. At least they have those dragons to blow things up."

"bʌt wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"But where are you going?" Perrin asked.

"səpoʊz aɪ ʃəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪt," mæt sɛd. "ðæt wɑz ðə ɹizən fəɹ miɾɪŋ wɪð ju, əsaɪd fɹəm ði eɪmiəbəl dɪskɔɹs ən ɔl." hi lin ɪn. "pɛɹɪn, mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz əlaɪv."

"Suppose I should explain it," Mat said. "That was the reason for meeting with you, aside from the amiable discourse and all." He leaned in. "Perrin, Moiraine is alive."

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ɪts tʃɹu," mæt sɛd. "ɔɹ, wɛl, wi θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪz. ʃi sɛn θɔɹn ə lɛɾɝ, kleɪmɪŋ ʃid fɔɹsin ðə bæɾəl wɪð lænfɝ, ən nu ðət ʃi wəd . . . wɛl, ɛniweɪ, ðɛɹz ðɪs taʊɝ wɛst ə hɪɹ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑɹi-nɛl. ɪts meɪɾ ɔl ə mɛɾəl. ɪt - "

"Its true," Mat said. "Or, well, we think it is. She sent Thorn a letter, claiming she'd foreseen the battle with Lanfear, and knew that she would . . . Well, anyway, there's this tower west of here on the River Ari-nelle. It's made all of metal. It - "

"ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "jɛs, aɪ noʊ ʌv ɪt."

"The Tower of Ghenjei," Perrin said softly. "Yes, I know of it."

mæt blɪŋkt. "ju du? bɝn mi. wən dɪd jə ɡɛt tə bi ə skɑlɝ?"

Mat blinked. "You do? Burn me. When did you get to be a scholar?"

"aɪv mɪɹli hɝd səm θɪŋz. mæt, ðət pleɪs ɪz ivəl."

"I've merely heard some things. Mat, that place is evil."

"wɛl, mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz ɪnsaɪd," mæt sɛd. "kæptʃɝd. aɪ min tə ɡɛɾ əɹ bæk. aɪ hæv tə bit ðə sneɪks ən ðə fɑksəz. blʌɾi tʃits."

"Well, Moiraine is inside," Mat said. "Captured. I mean to get her back. I have to beat the snakes and the foxes. Bloody cheats."

θɔɹn nɑɾəd. "ðə tʃɪlʒɹənz ɡeɪm ɪz neɪmd æftɝ ðə θɪŋz ðət lɪv ɪn ðə taʊɝ. soʊ wi θɪŋk."

Thorn nodded. "The children's game is named after the things that live in the tower. So we think."

"aɪv sin ðɛm," mæt sɛd. "ænd . . . wɛl, ðɛɹz ɹɪli nɑt taɪm fəɹ ðət naʊ."

"ɪf jəɹ gɑnə ɹɛskju hɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "pɝhæps aɪ kəd kʌm. əɹ ət list sɛnd wʌn ə ði æʃəmən."

Moraine explained it in her letter. Only three can come, and I know al-ready who they have to be." He hesitated. "Olver is going to bloody kill me for not taking him, you know."

nɪɹ ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə


Near Avendesora

eɪvinhə tʊk wʌn faɪnəl stɛp ən wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst ʌv ɡlæs pɪlɝz. ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ɡlæns bæk ət ðə pæθ ʃi hæd teɪkən.

Aviendha took one final step and was out of the forest of glass pillars. She took a deep breath, then glanced back at the path she had taken.

ðə sɛntʃɹəl plɑzə ʌv ɹɪɾiən wɑz ən ɑ-ɪnspaɪɹɪŋ saɪt. smuð waɪt flæɡstoʊnz kɑɹpəɾɪd ði ɪntaɪɝ skwɛɹ seɪv fəɹ ði æbsəlut sɛntɝ. ðəɹ stʊɾ ən ɪnɔɹməs tʃɹi, bɹæntʃəz spɹɛd waɪd laɪk ɑɹmz ɹitʃɪŋ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sʌn. ðə mæsɪv tʃɹi hæɾ ə pɝfɛkʃən ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn. ɪt hæɾ ə nætʃɹəl sɪmətʃɹi - noʊ mɪsɪŋ bɹæntʃəz, noʊ ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊlz ɪn ɪts lifi ʌpɝ ɹitʃəz. ɪt wɑz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪmpɹɛsɪv sɪns, wən ʃid læst sin ɪt, ɪt hæd bɪn blækən ən bɝnd.

The central plaza of Rhuidean was an awe-inspiring sight. Smooth white flagstones carpeted the entire square save for the absolute center. There stood an enormous tree, branches spread wide like arms reaching to embrace the sun. The massive tree had a perfection she could not explain. It had a natural symmetry - no missing branches, no gaping holes in its leafy upper reaches. It was particularly impressive since, when she'd last seen it, it had been blackened and burned.

ɪn ə wɝld wɛɹ ʌðɝ plæns wɝ daɪɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛkspləneɪʃən, ðɪs wʌn hild ən flɝɪʃt fæstɝ ðən ɛvɝ ʃʊɾə bɪn pɑsəbəl. ɪts livz ɹʌsəl suðɪŋli ɪn ðə wɪnd, ən ɪts nɑɹld ɹuts poʊk θɹu ðə ɡɹaʊn laɪk ði eɪdʒɪd fɪŋɡɝz ʌv ə waɪz ɛldɝ. ðə tʃɹi meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə sɪɾ ən bæsk ɪn ðə sɪmpəl pis ə ðə moʊmənt.

In a world where other plants were dying without explanation, this one healed and flourished faster than ever should have been possible. Its leaves rustled soothingly in the wind, and its gnarled roots poked through the ground like the aged fingers of a wise elder. The tree made her want to sit and bask in the simple peace of the moment.

ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðɪs tʃɹi wɝ ði aɪdil, ðə wʌn æftɝ wɪtʃ ɔl ʌðɝ tʃɹiz wɝ pæɾɝnd. ɪn lɛdʒən ɪt wɑz kɔld ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə. ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf.

It was as if this tree were the ideal, the one after which all other trees were patterned. In legend it was called Avendesora. The Tree of Life.

tə ðə saɪd sæt ðə ɡlæs kɑləmz. ðəɹ wɝ dʌzənz ə ðɛm, pɝhæps hʌnʒɹədz, fɔɹmɪŋ kənsɛntʃɹɪk ɹɪŋz. spɪnli ən θɪn, ðeɪ ɹitʃt haɪ ɪndə ðə skaɪ. əz pjʊɹli - ivən supɝləɾɪvli -  nætʃɹəl əz ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə wɑz, ðiz kɑləmz wɝ ikwəli nætʃɹəl. ðeɪ wɝ soʊ θɪn ən tɔl, lɑdʒɪk sɛd ðət ðə fɝst ɡʌst ʌv wɪnd ʃʊɾə tɑpəl ðɛm. ɪt wɑzn ðət ðeɪ wɝ æbɛɹənt, mɪɹli ɑɹɾəfɪʃəl.

To the side sat the glass columns. There were dozens of them, perhaps hundreds, forming concentric rings. Spindly and thin, they reached high into the sky. As purely - even superlatively -  natural as Avendesora was, these columns were equally natural. They were so thin and tall, logic said that the first gust of wind should have toppled them. It wasn't that they were aberrant, merely artificial.

"wɛn ʃi hæd fɝst ɛntɝd deɪz bɪfɔɹ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪn waɪt kɛɹfəli pɪkɪŋ ʌp fɔlən livz ən twɪɡz. ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃɹiɾəd əz sun əz ðeɪ hæd sin hɝ. wɑz ʃi ðə fɝs tə ɡoʊ θɹu ðə ɡlæs pɪlɝz sɪns ɹɪɾiənz tʃɹænsfɝmeɪʃən? hɝ oʊn klæn hæd sɛnt noʊ wʌn, ən ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ʃi wəɾ əv hɝɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɪf ði ʌðɝz hæd.

"When she had first entered days before, there had been gai'shain in white carefully picking up fallen leaves and twigs. They had retreated as soon as they had seen her. Was she the first to go through the glass pillars since Rhuidean's transformation? Her own clan had sent no one, and she was certain she would have heard of it if the others had.

ðət lɛft oʊnli ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, bʌt ðeɪ hæd ɹɪdʒɛktɪd ɹændz kleɪmz əbaʊt ði il oʊst. eɪvinhə səspɛktəd ðəɾ ɪf ɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd kʌm, ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə bɛɹ wʌt wɑz ʃoʊn hɪɹ.

That left only the Shaido, but they had rejected Rand's claims about the Aiel oast. Aviendha suspected that if any Shaido had come, they would not have been able to bear what was shown here.

ðeɪ wʊɾə pæst ɪndə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɡlæs kɑləmz ən nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝnd.

They would have passed into the center of the glass columns and never returned.

ðət hæd nɑt bɪn ðə keɪs fəɹ eɪvinhə. ʃi hæd sɝvaɪvd. ɪndid, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃid sin hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktəd. ɔlmoʊs dɪsəpɔɪntɪŋli soʊ.

That had not been the case for Aviendha. She had survived. Indeed, everything she'd seen had been expected. Almost disappointingly so.

ʃi saɪd, wɔkɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ɑvɛndɪsɹdz tʃɹʌŋk, ðən lʊkɪŋ ʌp θɹu ɪts wɛb ə bɹæntʃəz.

She sighed, walking over to Avendesords trunk, then looking up through its web of branches.

wʌns, ðɪs plɑzə hæd bɪn klʌɾɝd wɪð ʌðɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil; ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ ɹænd hæd fɝs dɪskʌvɝd ði æksɛs kiz i hæd juz tə klɛnz seɪɾɪn. ðət wɛlθ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz ɡɔn naʊ;

Once, this plaza had been cluttered with other ter'angreal; this was where Rand had first discovered the access keys he had used to cleanse saidin. That wealth of ter'angreal was gone now;

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd kleɪmd mɛni pisəz fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ði il u lɪv hɪɹ mʌst əv teɪkən ði ʌðɝz əweɪ. ðət lɛft oʊnli ðə tʃɹi, ðə kɑləmz ən ðə θɹi ɹɪŋz ðət wɪmən wɛn θɹu ɑn ðɛɹ fɝs tʃɹɪp hɪɹ, ðə tʃɹɪp ðət meɪɾ əm əpɹɛntəs waɪz wʌnz.
