Moiraine had claimed many pieces for the White Tower, and the Aiel who lived here must have taken the others away. That left only the tree, the columns and the three rings that women went through on their first trip here, the trip that made them apprentice Wise Ones.

ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd səm ə hɝ tʃɹɪp θɹu ðoʊz ɹɪŋz, wɪtʃ hæd ʃoʊɾ əɹ laɪf - hɝ mɛni pɑsəbəl laɪvz - tə hɝ. ɹɪli, oʊnli bɪts ən pisəz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn əɹ mɛmɹi. hɝ nɑlədʒ ðət ʃi wəd lʌv ɹænd, ðət ʃi wəɾ əv sɪstɝ-waɪvz. ɪnkluɾəd ɪn ðət nɑlədʒ wɑz ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət ʃid ɹɪtɝn hɪɹ, tə ɹɪɾiən. ʃi hæd noʊn, ðoʊ oʊnli stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðɪs kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ əɡɛn hæd spɑɹk səm ə ðoʊz mɛmɹiz tə laɪf ɪn əɹ maɪnd.

She remembered some of her trip through those rings, which had showed her life - her many possible lives - to her. Really, only bits and pieces remained in her memory. Her knowledge that she would love Rand, that she would have sister-wives. Included in that knowledge was the impression that she'd return here, to Rhuidean. She had known, though only stepping into this courtyard again had sparked some of those memories to life in her mind.

ʃi sæt daʊn kɹɔs-lɛɡəd bɪtwin tu ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz ɹuts. ðə sɑft wɪnd wɑz suðɪŋ, ði ɛɹ dʒɹaɪ ən fəmɪljɝ, ðə dʌsti sɛn ə ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ɹimaɪndɪŋ əɹ ə hɝ tʃaɪldhʊd.

She sat down cross-legged between two of the great tree's roots. The soft wind was soothing, the air dry and familiar, the dusty scent of the Three-fold Land reminding her of her childhood.

hɝ tʃɹɪp θɹu ðə kɑləmz hæd sɝɾənli bɪn ɪmɝsɪv. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə si ði ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ði il, pɝhæps wɪtnəs ðə deɪ wən ðeɪ hæd - -æz ə pipəl - dɪsaɪɾɪd tə teɪk ʌp ðə spɪɹz ən faɪt. ʃiɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ə noʊbəl dɪsɪʒən, wɛɹ ɑnɝ oʊvɝkeɪm ði ɪnfɪɹiɝ laɪfstaɪl dɪkteɪɾəd baɪ ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif.

Her trip through the columns had certainly been immersive. She had expected to see the origins of the Aiel, perhaps witness the day when they had - -as a people - decided to take up the spears and fight. She'd anticipated a noble decision, where honor overcame the inferior lifestyle dictated by the Way of the Leaf.

ʃi hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə si haʊ məndeɪn - ɔlmoʊst æksədɛntəl - ðə tʃɹu ɪvɛn hæd bɪn. noʊ ɡɹæn dɪsɪʒən; oʊnli ə mæn u hæd bɪn ənwɪlɪŋ tə lɛɾ ɪz fæmli bi mɝɾɝd. ðəɹ wɑz ɑnɝ ɪn wɑntɪŋ tə dɪfɛn ʌðɝz, bʌɾ i hæd nɑɾ əpɹoʊtʃt ɪz dɪsɪʒən wɪð ɑnɝ.

She had been surprised to see how mundane - almost accidental - the true event had been. No grand decision; only a man who had been unwilling to let his family be murdered. There was honor in wanting to defend others, but he had not approached his decision with honor.

ʃi ɹɛstəɾ əɹ hɛd bæk əɡɛns ðə tʃɹʌŋk ə ðə tʃɹi. ði il dɪd. dɪzɝv ðɛɹ pʌnɪʃmən ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, ən ðeɪ dɪɾ əv toʊ - əz ə pipəl - tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi hæd sin ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. bʌt mɛni ʌv ðə θɪŋz ʃi hæd bɪn hoʊpɪŋ tə lɝn hæd bɪn æbsənt. il wəd kəntɪnju tə vɪzət ðɪs pleɪs fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz, əz ðeɪ hæd fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz. ən itʃ ə ðɛm wəd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɑz naʊ kɑmən nɑlədʒ.

She rested her head back against the trunk of the tree. The Aiel did. deserve their punishment in the Three-fold Land, and they did have toh - as a people - to the Aes Sedai. She had seen everything she had expected. But many of the things she had been hoping to learn had been absent. Aiel would continue to visit this place for centuries, as they had for centuries. And each of them would learn something that was now common knowledge.

ðət bɑðɝɾ əɹ dipli.

That bothered her deeply.

ʃi lʊkt ʌpwɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ bɹæntʃəz kwɪvɝ ɪn ðə bɹiz, sɛvɹəl livz fɔlɪŋ ən dʒɹɪftɪŋ daʊn təwɔɹd hɝ. wʌn pæst əɹ feɪs, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ tʃik bɪfɔɹ əlaɪɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ ʃɔl.

She looked upward, watching branches quiver in the breeze, several leaves falling and drifting down toward her. One passed her face, brushing her cheek before alighting on her shawl.

pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡlæs kɑləmz wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə tʃælənʒ. ɝɪdʒənəli, ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil hæd pɹəvaɪɾəd ə tɛst. kəd ðə pətɛnʃəl liɾɝ feɪs ən æksɛp ði ilz dɑɹkəst sikɹət? əz ə meɪɾən, eɪvinhə hæd bɪn tɛstəɾ ɪn bɑɾi ən stʃɹɛŋkθ. bɪkʌmɪŋ ə waɪz wʌn tɛstəɾ ə pɝsən ɪmoʊʃnəli ən mɛntəli. ɹɪɾiən wɑz tə bi ðə kæpstoʊn ə ðət pɹɑsɛs, ðə faɪnəl tɛst ə mɛntəl ɛndɝəns. bʌt ðət tɛst wɑz ɡɔn naʊ.

Passing through the glass columns was no longer a challenge. Originally, this ter'angreal had provided a test. Could the potential leader face and accept the Aiel's darkest secret? As a Maiden, Aviendha had been tested in body and strength. Becoming a Wise One tested a person emotionally and mentally. Rhuidean was to be the capstone of that process, the final test of mental endurance. But that test was gone now.

mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, ʃi wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə bɪliv ðət tʃɹədɪʃən fəɹ ðə seɪk ə tʃɹədɪʃən wɑz fulɪʃnəs.

More and more, she was coming to believe that tradition for the sake of tradition was foolishness.

ɡʊd tʃɹədɪʃənz - stʃɹɔŋ, il tʃɹədɪʃənz - tɔt ðə weɪz ə dʒiɾoʊ, mɛθədz ə sɝvaɪvəl.

Good traditions - strong, Aiel traditions - taught the ways of ji'e'toh, methods of survival.

eɪvinhə saɪd, stændɪŋ. ðə fɔɹəst ə kɑləmz lʊk laɪk ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ laɪnz ə fɹoʊzən wɔɾɝ ʃi hæd sin dʊɹɪŋ wɪntɝ ɪn ðə wɛtlænz. aɪsɪkəlz, ɪleɪn hæd kɔl ðɛm. ðiz ɡɹu ʌp fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ, θɪŋz ə bjuɾi ən paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz sæd tə wɪtnəs ðɛɹ læps ɪndə ɪɹɛləvəns.

Aviendha sighed, standing. The forest of columns looked like the strange lines of frozen water she had seen during winter in the wetlands. Icicles, Elayne had called them. These grew up from the ground, pointing toward the sky, things of beauty and Power. It was sad to witness their lapse into irrelevance.

sʌmθɪŋ əkɝd tə hɝ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd lɛf keɪɛmlɪn, ʃi ən ɪleɪn hæd meɪɾ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl dɪskʌvɝi. eɪvinhə hæd mænəfɛstəɾ ə tælən ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ: ði əbɪləɾi tə aɪdɛntəfaɪ tɛɹæŋɡɹil.

Something occurred to her. Before she had left Caemlyn, she and Elayne had made a remarkable discovery. Aviendha had manifested a Talent in the One Power: the ability to identify ter'angreal.

kəd ʃi dətɝmən, ɪɡzækli, wʌt ðə ɡlæs pɪlɝz dɪd? ðeɪ kʊdn əv bɪn kɹieɪɾəd spəsɪfɪkli fəɹ ði il, kəd ðeɪ? moʊs θɪŋz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ laɪk ðɪs heɪl fɹəm vɛɹi eɪntʃən deɪz. ðə pɪlɝz wʊɾə bɪn kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðən ədæptəd tə ðə pɝpəs ə ʃoʊɪŋ ði il ðɛɹ tʃɹu pæst.

Could she determine, exactly, what the glass pillars did? They couldn't have been created specifically for the Aiel, could they? Most things of great Power like this hailed from very ancient days. The pillars would have been created during the Age of Legends, then adapted to the purpose of showing the Aiel their true past.

ðəɹ wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ dɪdnt noʊ əbaʊt tɛɹæŋɡɹil. hæd ði eɪntʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪli ʌndɝstʊd ðɛm, ðə seɪm weɪ eɪvinhə ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪɡzækli haʊ ə baʊ əɹ spɪɹ wɝkt? əɹ hæd ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz bɪn mɪstəfaɪd baɪ ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ kɹieɪɾəd? ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz soʊ wʌnʒɹəs, soʊ mɪstɪɹiəs, ðəɾ ivən wɝkɪŋ pɹæktəst wivz ɔfən meɪɾ eɪvinhə fil laɪk ə tʃaɪld.

There was so much they didn't know about ter'angreal. Had the ancient Aes Sedai really understood them, the same way Aviendha understood exactly how a bow or spear worked? Or had they themselves been mystified by the things they created? The One Power was so wondrous, so mysterious, that even working practiced weaves often made Aviendha feel like a child.

ʃi stɛpt ʌp tə ðə nɪɹəst ɡlæs pɪlɝ, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə pæs ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹɪŋ. ɪf ʃi tʌtʃt wʌn ə ðə ɹɑdz, pɝhæps əɹ tælənt wəd lɛɾ əɹ ɹɛd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə ɪkspɛɹəmənt wɪð tɛɹæŋɡɹil, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pæs ðɛɹ tʃælənʒ ən wɑz ənskeɪðd.

She stepped up to the nearest glass pillar, careful not to pass inside the ring. If she touched one of the rods, perhaps her Talent would let her read something about them. It was dangerous to experiment with ter'angreal, but she had already passed their challenge and was unscathed.

hɛzɪɾəntli, ʃi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən leɪd fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə slɪk, ɡlæsi sɝfəs. ɪt wɑz əbaʊɾ ə fʊt θɪk.

Hesitantly, she reached out and laid fingers on the slick, glassy surface. It was about a foot thick.

ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹid ðə pɪlɝz fʌŋkʃən.

She closed her eyes, trying to read the pillar's function.

ʃi sɛns ðə paʊɝfəl ɔɹə ʌv ðə pɪlɝ. ɪt wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ poʊɾənt ðən ɛni ʌv ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ʃi hæd hændəld wɪð ɪleɪn. ɪndid, ðə pɪlɝz simd . . əlaɪv, sʌmhaʊ. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ʃi kəd sɛns ən əwɛɹnəs fɹəm ðɛm.

She sensed the powerful aura of the pillar. It was far more potent than any of the ter'angreal she had handled with Elayne. Indeed, the pillars seemed . . alive, somehow. It was almost as if she could sense an awareness from them.

ðət ɡeɪv əɹ ə tʃɪl. wɑz ʃi tʌtʃɪŋ ðə pɪlɝ, əɹ wɑz ɪt tʌtʃɪŋ hɝ?

That gave her a chill. Was she touching the pillar, or was it touching her?

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹid tɛɹæŋɡɹil əz ʃi hæd dʌn bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðɪs wʌn wɑz væst. ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl, laɪk ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ʃi ɪnheɪld ʃɑɹpli, dɪsɔɹiɛntɪd baɪ ðə weɪɾ ʌv wʌt ʃi fɛlt. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ʃi hæd sʌɾənli fɔlən ɪndə ə dip, dɑɹk pɪt.

She tried to read ter'angreal as she had done before, but this one was vast. Incomprehensible, like the One Power itself. She inhaled sharply, disoriented by the weight of what she felt. It was as if she had suddenly fallen into a deep, dark pit.

ʃi snæpt əɹ aɪz oʊpən, pʊlɪŋ əɹ hæn əweɪ, pɑm kwɪvɝɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz bɪɑn hɝ. ʃi wɑz ən ɪnsɛkt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɹæsp ðə saɪz ən mæs ʌv ə maʊntən. ʃi tʊk ə bɹɛθ tə stɛɾi hɝsɛlf, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ tə bi dʌn hɪɹ.

She snapped her eyes open, pulling her hand away, palm quivering. This was beyond her. She was an insect, trying to grasp the size and mass of a mountain. She took a breath to steady herself, then shook her head. There was nothing more to be done here.

ʃi tɝn fɹəm ðə ɡlæs pɪlɝz ən tʊk ə stɛp.

She turned from the glass pillars and took a step.

ʃi wɑz mɑlədʒɹə, eɪtin bʌt skɹɔni ɪnʌf tə əpɪɹ mʌtʃ jʌŋɡɝ. ʃi kɹɔld ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. kɛɹfəl. kwaɪət. ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə ɡɛt ðɪs kloʊs tə ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz. hʌŋɡɝ dʒɹoʊv əɹ fɔɹwɝd. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dɪd.

She was Malidra, eighteen but scrawny enough to appear much younger. She crawled in the darkness. Careful. Quiet. It was dangerous to get this close to the Lightmakers. Hunger drove her forward. It always did.

ðə naɪt wɑz koʊld, ðə lændskeɪp bæɹən. mɑlədʒɹə hæd hɝd stɔɹiz ʌv ə pleɪs bɪɑn ðə dɪstən maʊntənz, wɛɹ ðə lænd wɑz ɡɹin ən fud ɡɹu ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ʃi dɪdn bɪliv ðoʊz laɪz. ðə maʊntənz wɝ dʒʌs laɪnz ɪn ðə skaɪ, dʒæɡd tiθ. hu kəd klaɪm sʌmθɪŋ soʊ tɔl?

The night was cold, the landscape barren. Malidra had heard stories of a place beyond the distant mountains, where the land was green and food grew everywhere. She didn't believe those lies. The mountains were just lines in the sky, jagged teeth. Who could climb something so tall?

meɪbi ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz kʊd. ðeɪ dɪd kʌm fɹəm ðət dɝɛkʃən, juʒəwəli. ðɛɹ kæmp wɑz əhɛɾ ə hɝ, ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ðət ɡloʊ wɑz tu stɛɾi tə bi faɪɝ. ɪt keɪm fɹəm ðə bɔlz ðeɪ kæɹid wɪð ðɛm. ʃi ɪntʃt kloʊsɝ, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, bɛɹ kəɾ ən hænz dʌsti. ðəɹ wɝ ə fju mɛn ən wɪmən ə ðə foʊk wɪð hɝ. ɡɹaɪmi feɪsəz, stʃɹɪŋi hɛɹ. ɹæɡəd bɪɹdz ɑn ðə mɛn.

Maybe the Lightmakers could. They did come from that direction, usually. Their camp was ahead of her, glowing in the darkness. That glow was too steady to be fire. It came from the balls they carried with them. She inched closer, crouching, bare ket and hands dusty. There were a few men and women of the Folk with her. Grimy faces, stringy hair. Ragged beards on the men.

ə mɪʃmæʃ ə kloʊðɪŋ. tæɾɝd tʃɹaʊzɝz, ɡɑɹməns ðət maɪt wʌns əv bɪn ʃɝts. ɛniθɪŋ tə kip ðə sʌn ɔf dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ, kəz ðə sʌn kəd kɪl. ən dɪd. mɑlədʒɹə wɑz ðə læst ə fɔɹ sɪstɝz, tu dɛd baɪ ðə sʌn ən hʌŋɡɝ, wʌn dɛd fɹəm ðə baɪɾ ʌv ə sneɪk.

A mishmash of clothing. Tattered trousers, garments that might once have been shirts. Anything to keep the sun off during the day, because the sun could kill. And did. Malidra was the last of four sisters, two dead by the sun and hunger, one dead from the bite of a snake.

bʌt mɑlədʒɹə sɝvaɪvd. æŋkʃəsli, ʃi sɝvaɪvd. ðə bɛst weɪ wɑz tə fɑloʊ ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz. ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ əɹ maɪn bɛɹli noʊɾəst deɪnʒɝ ɛnimɔɹ. ðət wɑz wʌt hæpənd wən vɝtʃuəli ɛniθɪŋ kəd kɪl ju.

But Malidra survived. Anxiously, she survived. The best way was to follow the Lightmakers. It was dangerous, but her mind barely noticed danger anymore. That was what happened when virtually anything could kill you.

mɑlədʒɹə pæst ə bʊʃ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə laɪtmeɪkɝ ɡɑɹdz. tu sɛntʃɹiz, kæɹiɪŋ ðɛɹ lɔŋ, ɹɑdlaɪk wɛpənz. mɑlədʒɹə hæd faʊnd wʌn ɑn ə dɛd mæn wʌns, bʌt ʃi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk ɪt də ɛniθɪŋ.

Malidra passed a bush, watching the Lightmaker guards. Two sentries, carrying their long, rodlike weapons. Malidra had found one on a dead man once, but she hadn't been able to make it do anything.

ðə laɪtmək-ɝz hæd mæɡɪks, ðə seɪm mæɡɪks ðət kɹieɪɾəd ðɛɹ fuɾ ən ðɛɹ laɪts mæɡɪks ðət kɛpt əm wɔɹm ɪn ðə bɪɾɝ koʊld ət naɪt.

The Lightmak-ers had magics, the same magics that created their food and their lights Magics that kept them warm in the bitter cold at night.

ðə tu mɛn wɔɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ kloʊðɪŋ. tʃɹaʊzɝz ðət fɪt tu wɛl, koʊts kʌvɝd wɪð pɑkəts ən ɡlɪsnɪŋ bɪts ə mɛɾəl. boʊθ hæd hæts, ðoʊ wʌn wɔɹ ɪz bæk, hɛld ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk baɪ ə θɪn lɛðɝ stʃɹæp ðə mɛn tʃæɾəd. ðeɪ dɪdn əv bɪɹdz laɪk ðə foʊk dɪd. ðɛɹ hɛɹ wɑz dɑɹkɝ.

The two men wore strange clothing. Trousers that fit too well, coats covered with pockets and glistening bits of metal. Both had hats, though one wore his back, held around his neck by a thin leather strap The men chatted. They didn't have beards like the Folk did. Their hair was darker.

wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ foʊk ɡɑt tu kloʊs, ən mɑlədʒɹə hɪst ət hɝ. ðə wʊmən ʃɑt bæk ə ɡlɛɹ, bʌt muvd əweɪ. mɑlədʒɹə steɪɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə laɪt. ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz wʊdn si hɝ. ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ ɡloʊɪŋ ɔɹbz ɹuən ðɛɹ naɪt vɪʒən.

One of the other Folk got too close, and Malidra hissed at her. The woman shot back a glare, but moved away. Malidra stayed at the edge of the light. The Lightmakers wouldn't see her. Their strange glowing orbs ruined their night vision.

ʃi ɹaʊndəd ðɛɹ mæsɪv wæɡən. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ hɔɹsəz. oʊnli ðə wæɡən, lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə haʊs ə dʌzən pipəl. ɪt muv mædʒɪkəli dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪlaɪt, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn wilz nɪɹli əz waɪɾ əz mɑlədʒɹə wɑz tɔl. ʃi hæd hɝd - ɪn ðə hʌʃt, bɹoʊkən kəmjunəkeɪʃən ə foʊk - ðəɾ ɪn ði ist, ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz wɝ kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə mæsɪv ɹoʊdweɪ. ɪt wəd pæs dɝɛkli θɹu ðə weɪst. ɪt wɑz meɪd baɪ leɪɪŋ daʊn stʃɹeɪnʒ pisəz ə mɛɾəl. ðeɪ wɝ tu bɪɡ tə pɹaɪ ʌp, ðoʊ dʒɔɹʃəm hæd ʃoʊn əɹ ə lɑɹdʒ neɪl i hæd faʊnd. hi juzd ɪt tə skɹeɪp miɾ ɔf boʊnz.

She rounded their massive wagon. There were no horses. Only the wagon, large enough to house a dozen people. It moved magically during the daylight, rolling on wheels nearly as wide as Malidra was tall. She had heard - in the hushed, broken communication of Folk - that in the east, the Lightmakers were creating a massive roadway. It would pass directly through the Waste. It was made by laying down strange pieces of metal. They were too big to pry up, though Jorshem had shown her a large nail he had found. He used it to scrape meat off bones.

ɪt hæd bɪn kwaɪɾ ə waɪl sɪns ʃi hæɾ iɾən wɛl - nɑt sɪns ðeɪd mænədʒ tə kɪl ðət mɝtʃən ɪn ɪz slip tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ʃi kəd stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət fist, dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz stɔɹz, iɾɪŋ əntɪl əɹ stʌmək ætʃt. sətʃ ən ɑd filɪŋ. wʌnʒɹəs ən peɪnfəl.

It had been quite a while since she had eaten well - not since they'd managed to kill that merchant in his sleep two years ago. She could still remember that feast, digging into his stores, eating until her stomach ached. Such an odd feeling. Wondrous and painful.

moʊs laɪtmeɪkɝz wɝ tu kɛɹfəl fəɹ əɹ tə kɪl əm ɪn ðɛɹ slip. ʃi dɪdn dɛɹ feɪs əm wən ðeɪ wɝ əweɪk. ðeɪ kəd meɪk wʌn sətʃ əz əɹ vænɪʃ wɪð ə stɛɹ.

Most Lightmakers were too careful for her to kill them in their sleep. She didn't dare face them when they were awake. They could make one such as her vanish with a stare.

nɝvəsli, tʃɹeɪl baɪ ə kʌpəl ʌv ʌðɝ foʊk, ʃi ɹaʊndəd ðə wæɡən ən əpɹoʊtʃt ɪt fɹəm ðə bæk. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, hɪɹ ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz hæd tɔst səm ə ðə livɪŋz fɹəm ðɛɹ ɝliɝ mil. ʃi skʌɾəld fɔɹwɝɾ ən bɪɡæn tə dɪɡ θɹu ðə tʃɹæʃ. ðəɹ wɝ səm kʌɾɪŋz ə mit, stʃɹɪps ə fæt.

Nervously, trailed by a couple of other Folk, she rounded the wagon and approached it from the back. Sure enough, here the Lightmakers had tossed some of the leavings from their earlier meal. She scuttled forward and began to dig through the trash. There were some cuttings of meat, strips of fat.

ʃi snætʃt ðiz ʌp iɡɝli - hoʊldɪŋ əm kloʊs bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝz kəd si - ən stʌft əm ɪndə hɝ maʊθ. ʃi fɛl dɝt ɡɹaɪn əɡɛnst əɹ tiθ, bʌt mit wɑz fud. ʃi hɝidli pɪk θɹu ðə weɪst səm mɔɹ.

She snatched these up eagerly - holding them close before the others could see - and stuffed them into her mouth. She felt dirt grind against her teeth, but meat was food. She hurriedly picked through the waste some more.

ə bɹaɪt laɪt ʃoʊn ɑn hɝ. ʃi fɹoʊz, hæn hæfweɪ tə hɝ maʊð. ði ʌðɝ tu foʊk skɹimd, skɹæmbəlɪŋ əweɪ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə də laɪkwaɪz bʌt tʃɹɪpt. ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪs ə saʊnd - wʌn ə ðə laɪtmeɪkɝ wɛpənz - ən sʌmθɪŋ pɑpt əɡɛnst əɹ bæk. ɪt fɛlt laɪk ʃid bɪn hɪt wɪð ə smɔl ɹɑk.

A bright light shone on her. She froze, hand halfway to her mouth. The other two Folk screamed, scrambling away. She tried to do likewise but tripped. There was a hiss of sound - one of the Lightmaker weapons - and something popped against her back. It felt like she'd been hit with a small rock.

ʃi kəlæpst, ðə peɪn sʌɾən ən ʃɑɹp. ðə laɪt feɪɾəd slaɪtli. ʃi blɪŋkt, aɪz ədʒʌstɪŋ ivən əz ʃi fɛlt əɹ laɪf sipɪŋ aʊɾ ən ɝaʊn əɹ hænz.

She collapsed, the pain sudden and sharp. The light faded slightly. She blinked, eyes adjusting even as she felt her life seeping out and around her hands.

"aɪ toʊl ju," ə vɔɪs sɛd. tu ʃædoʊz muvd ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə laɪt. ʃi hæd tə ɹʌn! ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹaɪz, bʌɾ oʊnli mænədʒ tə θɹæʃ wikli.

"I told you," a voice said. Two shadows moved in front of the light. She had to run! She tried to rise, but only managed to thrash weakly.

"blʌɾ ən tʃɑɹ, flɝn," ə sɛkən vɔɪs sɛd. ə sɪləwɛt nɛl bɪsaɪd hɝ. "pʊɹ θɪŋ. ɔlmoʊst ə tʃaɪld. ʃi wɑzn duɪŋ ɛni hɑɹm."

"Blood and char, Flern," a second voice said. A silhouette knelt beside her. "Poor thing. Almost a child. She wasn't doing any harm."

flɝn snɔɹɾɪd. "noʊ hɑɹm? aɪv sin ðiz kɹitʃɝz tʃɹaɪ tə slɪɾ ə slipɪŋ mænz θɹoʊt. ɔl fəɹ ɪz tʃɹæʃ. blʌɾi pɛsts."

Flern snorted. "No harm? I've seen these creatures try to slit a sleeping man's throat. All for his trash. Bloody pests."

ði ʌðɝ ʃædoʊ lʊkt ət hɝ, ən ʃi kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ə ɡɹɪm feɪs. twɪŋkəlɪŋ aɪz. laɪk stɑɹz.

The other shadow looked at her, and she caught sight of a grim face. Twinkling eyes. Like stars.

ðə mæn saɪd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "nɛks taɪm wi bɛɹi ðə tʃɹæʃ." hi ɹitʃɹiɾəd bæk təwɔɹd ðə laɪt.

The man sighed, rising. "Next time we bury the trash." He retreated back toward the light.

ðə sɛkən mæn, flɝn, stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. wɑz ðəɾ əɹ blʌd? ɔl oʊvɝ əɹ hænz, wɔɹm, laɪk wɔɾɝ ðət hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn fəɹ tu lɔŋ?

The second man, Flern, stood watching her. Was that her blood? All over her hands, warm, like water that had been sitting in the sun for too long?

dɛθ dɪd nɑt sɝpɹaɪz hɝ. ɪn ə weɪ, ʃid bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪt fəɹ moʊst ə hɝ eɪtin jɪɹz.

Death did not surprise her. In a way, she'd been expecting it for most of her eighteen years.

"blʌɾi il," flɝn sɛɾ əz əɹ saɪt feɪɾəd.

"Bloody Aiel," Flern said as her sight faded.

eɪvinhəz fʊt hɪt ðə flæɡstoʊn ɪn ɹɪɾiənz skwɛɹ, ən ʃi blɪŋkt ɪn ʃɑk. ðə sʌn hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv. aʊɝz hæd pæst.

Aviendha's foot hit the flagstone in Rhuidean's square, and she blinked in shock. The sun had changed in the sky above. Hours had passed.

wʌt hæd hæpənd? ðə vɪʒən hæd bɪn soʊ ɹil, laɪk əɹ vjuɪŋz ə ði ɝli deɪz ə hɝ pipəl. bʌt ʃi kəd meɪk noʊ sɛns ʌv ɪt. hæd ʃi ɡɔn ivən fɑɹðɝ bæk ɪndə hɪstɝi? ðət sim laɪk ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ məʃinz, kloʊðɪŋ, ən wɛpənz. bʌt ðət bæd bɪn ðə weɪst.

What had happened? The vision had been so real, like her viewings of the early days of her people. But she could make no sense of it. Had she gone even farther back into history? That seemed like the Age of Legends. The strange machines, clothing, and weapons. But that bad been the Waste.

ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ dɪstɪŋkli biɪŋ mɑlədʒɹə. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ jɪɹz ə hʌŋɡɝ, ʌv skævənʒəŋ, ʌv heɪtʃɹəd - ən fɪɹ - ʌv ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ dɛθ. ðə tɛɹɝ, tʃɹæpt ən bliɾɪŋ. ðət wɔɹm blʌɾ ɑn əɹ hænz. . . .

She could remember distinctly being Malidra. She could remember years of hunger, of scavenging, of hatred - and fear - of the Lightmakers. She remembered her death. The terror, trapped and bleeding. That warm blood on her hands. . . .

ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ hɛd, sɪk ən ənsɛɾəld. nɑt baɪ ðə dɛθ. ɛvɹiwʌn woʊk fɹəm ðə dʒɹim, ən waɪl ʃi dɪd nɑt wɛlkəm ɪt, ʃi wəd nɑt fɪɹ ɪt. noʊ, ðə hɔɹəbəl θɪŋ əbaʊt ðə vɪʒən hæd bɪn ðə kəmplit læk ʌv ɑnɝ ʃid sin. kɪlɪŋ mɛn ɪn ðə naɪt fəɹ ðɛɹ fud?

She raised a hand to her head, sick and unsettled. Not by the death. Everyone woke from the dream, and while she did not welcome it, she would not fear it. No, the horrible thing about the vision had been the complete lack of honor she'd seen. Killing men in the night for their food?

skævənʒəŋ fəɹ hæf-tʃud miɾ ɪn ðə dɝt? wɛɹɪŋ skɹæps? ʃid bɪn mɔɹ ən ænəməl ðən ə pɝsən!

Scavenging for half-chewed meat in the dirt? Wearing scraps? She'd been more an animal than a person!

bɛɾɝ tə daɪ. ʃʊɹli ði il kʊdn əv kʌm fɹəm ɹuts laɪk ðoʊz, lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ði il ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz hæd bɪn pisfəl sɝvəns ɹeɪ-spɛktɪd. haʊ kəd ðeɪv stɑɹɾəd əz skævənʒɝz?

Better to die. Surely the Aiel couldn't have come from roots like those, long ago. The Aiel in the Age of Legends had been peaceful servants re-spected. How could they have started as scavengers?

pɝhæps ðɪs wɑz mɪɹli wʌn taɪni ɡɹup ʌv il. əɹ meɪbi ðə mæn hæd bɪn mɪsteɪkən. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl weɪ tə tɛl fɹəm ðɪs sɪŋɡəl vɪʒən. waɪ hæd ʃi bɪn ʃoʊn ɪt?

Perhaps this was merely one tiny group of Aiel. Or maybe the man had been mistaken. There was little way to tell from this single vision. Why had she been shown it?

ʃi tʊk ə hɛzɪɾənt stɛp əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡlæs kɑləmz, ən nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. noʊ fɝðɝ vɪʒənz.

She took a hesitant step away from the glass columns, and nothing happened. No further visions.

dɪstɝbd, ʃi bɪɡæn tə wɔk fɹəm ðə plɑzə.

Disturbed, she began to walk from the plaza.

ðən ʃi sloʊd.

Then she slowed.

hɛzɪɾəntli ʃi tɝn bæk. ðə kɑləmz stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɪmɪŋ laɪt, kwaɪəɾ ən əloʊn, simɪŋ tə bʌz wɪð ən ənsin ɛnɝdʒi.

Hesitantly she turned back. The columns stood in the dimming light, quiet and alone, seeming to buzz with an unseen energy.

wɑz ðəɹ mɔɹ?

Was there more?

ðət wʌn vɪʒən sim soʊ dɪskənɛktɪd fɹəm ði ʌðɝz ʃid sin. ɪf ʃi pæst ɪndə ðə kɑləmz' mɪdst əɡɛn, wəd ʃi ɹɪpit wʌt ʃid bɪn ɡɪvən bɪfɔɹ? əɹ . . . hæd ʃi, pɝhæps, tʃeɪnʒd sʌmθɪŋ wɪð əɹ tælənt?

That one vision seemed so disconnected from the others she'd seen. If she passed into the columns' midst again, would she repeat what she'd been given before? Or . . . had she, perhaps, changed something with her Talent?

ɪn ðə sɛntʃɝiz sɪns ɹɪɾiənz faʊndɪŋ, ðoʊz kɑləmz hæd ʃoʊn ði il wʌt ðeɪ niɾəd tə noʊ əbaʊt ðɛmsɛlvz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd sɛt ðəɾ ʌp, hædn ðeɪ? əɹ hæd ðeɪ sɪmpli pleɪs ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən əlaʊɾ ɪt tə də wʌɾ ɪt plizd, noʊɪŋ ɪt wəd ɡɹænt wɪzdəm?

In the centuries since Rhuidean's founding, those columns had shown the Aiel what they needed to know about themselves. The Aes Sedai had set that up, hadn't they? Or had they simply placed the ter'angreal and allowed it to do what it pleased, knowing it would grant wisdom?

eɪvinhə lɪsən tə ðə tʃɹiz livz ɹʌsəl. ðoʊz pɪlɝz wɝ ə tʃælənʒ, əz ʃʊɹ əz ən ɛnəmi wɔɹiɝ wɪð ɪz spɪɹ ɪn hænd. ɪf ʃi pæst ɪndə ðɛɹ mɪdst əɡɛn, ʃi maɪt nɛvɝ kʌm aʊt; noʊbɑdi vɪzəɾəd ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil ə sɛkən taɪm. ɪt wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən. wʌn tʃɹɪp θɹu ðə ɹɪŋz, wʌn θɹu ðə kɑləmz.

Aviendha listened to the tree's leaves rustle. Those pillars were a challenge, as sure as an enemy warrior with his spear in hand. If she passed into their midst again, she might never come out; nobody visited this ter'angreal a second time. It was forbidden. One trip through the rings, one through the columns.

bʌt ʃi hæd kʌm sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ. ʃi wəd nɑt liv wɪθaʊɾ ɪt. ʃi tɝn ən - teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ - wɔkt ʌp tə ðə pɪlɝz.

But she had come seeking knowledge. She would not leave without it. She turned and - taking a deep breath - walked up to the pillars.

ðən tʊk ə stɛp.

Then took a step.

ʃi wɑz nɔɹlɪʃ. ʃi hɛld əɹ jʌŋɡəs tʃaɪl kloʊs tə hɝ bʊzəm. ə dʒɹaɪ wɪn tʌɡd əɾ əɹ ʃɔl. hɝ beɪbi, ɡɑɹlvən, stɑɹɾəd tə wɪmpɝ, bʌt ʃi kwaɪəɾəd ɪm əz əɹ hʌzbən spoʊk wɪð ði aʊtləndɝz.

She was Norlesh. She held her youngest child close to her bosom. A dry wind tugged at her shawl. Her baby, Garlvan, started to whimper, but she quieted him as her husband spoke with the outlanders.

ən aʊtləndɝ vɪlədʒ stʊɾ ɪn ðə nɪɹ dɪstəns, bɪlt ə ʃæks əɡɛns ðə fʊthɪlz ə ðə maʊntənz. ðeɪ wɔɹ daɪd kloʊðɪŋ ən stʃɹeɪnʒli kʌt tʃɹaʊzɝz wɪð bʌtoʊnɪŋ ʃɝts. ðeɪ hæd kʌm fəɹ ði ɔɹ. haʊ kəd ɹɑks bi soʊ væljəbəl ðət ðeɪ wəd lɪv ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntənz, əweɪ fɹəm ðɛɹ feɪbəld læn ʌv wɔɾɝ ən fud? əweɪ fɹəm ðɛɹ bɪldɪŋz wɛɹ laɪt ʃoʊn wɪθaʊt kændəlz ən ðɛɹ kɑɹts ðət muvd wɪθaʊt hɔɹsəz?

An outlander village stood in the near distance, built of shacks against the foothills of the mountains. They wore dyed clothing and strangely cut trousers with buttoning shirts. They had come for the ore. How could rocks be so valuable that they would live on this side of the mountains, away from their fabled land of water and food? Away from their buildings where light shone without candles and their carts that moved without horses?

hɝ ʃɔl slɪpt ən ʃi pʊld ɪɾ ʌp. ʃi niɾəd ə nu wʌn; ðɪs wʌn wɑz ɹæɡəd, ən ʃi dɪdn əv ɛni mɔɹ θɹɛd lɛft fəɹ pætʃɪŋ. ɡɑɹlvən wɪmpɝɾ ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz, ən əɹ oʊnli ʌðɝ lɪvɪŋ tʃaɪld - mis - hɛl tə hɝ skɝts. mis hædn spoʊkən fəɹ mɑnɹs, naʊ. nɑt sɪns əɹ oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ hæd daɪd fɹəm ɪkspoʊʒɝ.

Her shawl slipped and she pulled it up. She needed a new one; this one was ragged, and she didn't have any more thread left for patching. Garlvan whimpered in her arms, and her only other living child - Meise - held to her skirts. Meise hadn't spoken for monrhs, now. Not since her older brother had died from exposure.

"pliz," sɛɾ əɹ hʌzbənd - mɛtɑlən - tə ði aʊtləndɝz. ðəɹ wɝ θɹi ʌv ðɛm, tu mɛn ən ə wʊmən, ɔl wɛɹɪŋ tʃɹaʊzɝz. ɹʌɡəd foʊk, nɑt laɪk ði ʌðɝ fɔɹənɝz, wɪð ðɛɹ dɛləkət fitʃɝz ən tu-faɪn sɪlks. ɪluməneɪɾəd wʌnz, ðoʊz ʌðɝz səmtaɪmz kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz. ðiz θɹi wɝ mɔɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi.

"Please," said her husband - Metalan - to the outlanders. There were three of them, two men and a woman, all wearing trousers. Rugged folk, not like the other foreigners, with their delicate features and too-fine silks. Illuminated Ones, those others sometimes called themselves. These three were more ordinary.

"pliz," mɛtɑlən ɹɪpiɾɪd. "maɪ fæmli . . ."

"Please," Metalan repeated. "My family . . ."

hi wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn. əɹ i hæd bɪn wʌns, bæk wən hid bɪn stʃɹɔŋ ən fɪt. naʊ hi simd ə ʃɛl ə ðət mæn, hɪz tʃiks sʌŋkən. hɪz wʌns-vaɪbɹən blu aɪz stɛɹɾ æbsənli mʌtʃ ə ðə taɪm.

He was a good man. Or he had been once, back when he'd been strong and fit. Now he seemed a shell of that man, his cheeks sunken. His once-vibrant blue eyes stared absently much of the time.

hɔntəd. ðət lʊk keɪm fɹəm wɑtʃɪŋ θɹi ʌv ɪz tʃɪlʒɹən daɪ ɪn eɪtin mʌnθs' taɪm. ðoʊ mɛtɑlən wɑz ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ði aʊtləndɝz, hi sim tə ɡɹɑvəl bɪfɔɹ ðɛm.

Haunted. That look came from watching three of his children die in eighteen months' time. Though Metalan was a head taller than any of the outlanders, he seemed to grovel before them.

ðə lɛɾ aʊtləndɝ - ə mæn wɪð ə bʊʃi bɪɹɾ ən waɪd, ɑnəst aɪz - ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi ɹɪtɝn tə mɛtɑlən ðə sæk fʊl ə stoʊnz. "ðə ɹeɪvən ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi ɔlweɪz dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ, fɝbɪdz ɪt. noʊ tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ wɪð il. wi kəd bi stʃɹɪpt ʌv əɹ tʃɑɹɾɝ fəɹ tɔkɪŋ tə ju."

The lead outlander - a man with a bushy beard and wide, honest eyes - shook his head. He returned to Metalan the sack full of stones. "The Raven Empress, may she always draw breath, forbids it. No trading with Aiel. We could be stripped of our charter for talking to you."

"wi hæv noʊ fud," mɛtɑlən sɛd. "maɪ tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ stɑɹvɪŋ. ðiz stoʊnz kənteɪn ɔɹ. aɪ noʊ ðəɾ ɪts ðə taɪp fəɹ wɪtʃ jə sɝtʃ. aɪ spɛnt wiks ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪt. ɡɪv əs ə bɪɾ ə fud. sʌmθɪŋ.

"We have no food," Metalan said. "My children are starving. These stones contain ore. I know that it is the type for which you search. I spent weeks gathering it. Give us a bit of food. Something.

pliz."

Please."

"sɑɹi, fɹɛnd," ðə lɛɾ aʊtləndɝ sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪzənt wɝθ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ðə ɹeɪvənz. ɡoʊ ɑn jəɹ weɪ.

"Sorry, friend," the lead outlander said. "It isn't worth trouble with the Ravens. Go on your way.

wi doʊnt wɑn ən ɪnsəɾənt." sɛvɹəl aʊtləndɝz əpɹoʊtʃt fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, wʌn kæɹiɪŋ ən æks, tu ʌðɝz wɪð hɪs-steɪvz.

We don't want an incident." Several outlanders approached from behind, one carrying an axe, two others with hiss-staves.

hɝ hʌzbən slʌmpt. deɪz ə tʃɹævəl, wiks ə sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə stoʊnz. fəɹ nʌθɪŋ. hi tɝn ən wɔk bæk tə hɝ. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ðə sʌn wɑz sɛɾɪŋ. wʌns i ɹitʃt hɝ, ʃi ən mis dʒɔɪn hɪm, wɔkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ði aʊtləndɝ kæmp.

Her husband slumped. Days of travel, weeks of searching for the stones. For nothing. He turned and walked back to her. In the distance, the sun was setting. Once he reached her, she and Meise joined him, walking away from the outlander camp.

mis bɪɡæn tə snɪfəl, bʌt niðɝ ə ðɛm hæd ðə wɪl əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ tə kæɹi hɝ. əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ əweɪ fɹəm ði aʊtləndɝ kæmp, hɝ hʌzbən faʊn ə hɑloʊ ɪn ə ɹɑk ʃɛlf. ðeɪ sɛɾəld ɪn, nɑt meɪkɪŋ ə faɪɝ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bɝn.

Meise began to sniffle, but neither of them had the will or strength to carry her. About an hour away from the outlander camp, her husband found a hollow in a rock shelf. They settled in, not making a fire. There was nothing to burn.

nɔɹlɪʃ wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ. bʌt . . . filɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ sim dɪfəkəlt. "aɪm soʊ hʌŋɡɹi," ʃi wɪspɝd.

Norlesh wanted to cry. But . . . feeling anything seemed difficult. "I'm so hungry," she whispered.

"aɪ wɪl tʃɹæp sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," hɝ hʌzbən sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə stɑɹz.

"I will trap something in the morning," her husband said, staring up at the stars.

"wi hævən kɑɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn deɪz," ʃi sɛd.

"We haven't caught anything in days," she said.

hi dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ.

He didn't reply.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" ʃi wɪspɝd. "wi hævən bɪn eɪbəl ti kip ə hoʊm fəɹ əɹ pipəl sɪns maɪ ɡɹieɪtmɑðɝ tɑvəz deɪ. ɪf wi ɡæðɝ ðeɪ ətæk ʌs. ɪf wi wɑndɝ ðə weɪst, wi daɪ ɔf.

"What are we going to do?" she whispered. "We haven't been able t keep a home for our people since my greatmother Tava's day. If we gather they attack us. If we wander the Waste, we die off.

ðeɪ woʊn tʃɹeɪd wɪð ʌs. ðeɪ woʊn lɛɾ əs kɹɔs ðə maʊntənz. wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

They won't trade with us. They won't let us cross the mountains. What are we going to do?"

hɪz ɹɪspɑns wɑz tə laɪ daʊn, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ.

His response was to lie down, turning away from her.

hɝ tɪɹz dɪd kʌm ðɛn, kwaɪət, wik. ðeɪ ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ tʃiks əz ʃi əndɪɾ əɹ ʃɝt tə nɝs ɡɑɹlvən, ðoʊ ʃi hæd noʊ sʌk fəɹ hɪm.

Her tears did come then, quiet, weak. They rolled down her cheeks as she undid her shirt to nurse Garlvan, though she had no suck for him.

hi dɪdn muv. hi dɪdn lætʃ ɑn. ʃi lɪftəɾ ɪz smɔl fɔɹm ən ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɹiðɪŋ. sʌmwɛɹ əlɔŋ ðə wɔk tə ðə hɑloʊ, hi hæd daɪd wɪθaʊɾ əɹ ɹilaɪzɪŋ ɪt.

He didn't move. He didn't latch on. She lifted his small form and realized that he was no longer breathing. Somewhere along the walk to the hollow, he had died without her realizing it.

ðə moʊs fɹaɪɾənɪŋ pɑɹt wɑz haʊ dɪfəkəlt ʃi faʊn ɪt tə sʌmən ɛni sɑɹoʊ ət ðə dɛθ.

The most frightening part was how difficult she found it to summon any sorrow at the death.

eɪvinhəz fʊt hɪt ðə flæɡstoʊnz. ɝaʊn hɝ, ðə fɔɹəst ʌv ɡlæs kɑləmz ʃɪmɝd wɪð pɹɪzmæɾɪk kʌlɝ. ɪt wɑz laɪk stændɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz faɪɝwɝk. ðə sʌn wɑz haɪ ɪn ðə skaɪ, klaʊd kʌvɝ ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ɡɔn.

Aviendha's foot hit the flagstones. Around her, the forest of glass columns shimmered with prismatic color. It was like standing in the middle of an Illuminator's firework. The sun was high in the sky, cloud cover remarkably gone.

ʃi wɑntəd tə liv ðə skwɛɹ fɝɛvɝ. ʃi hæd bɪn pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ðə nɑlədʒ ðət ði il hæd wʌns fɑloʊd ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif. ðət nɑlədʒ wɑzn vɛɹi dɪstɝbɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd sun fʊlfɪl ðɛɹ toʊ.

She wanted to leave the square forever. She had been prepared for the knowledge that the Aiel had once followed the Way of the Leaf. That knowledge wasn't very disturbing. They would soon fulfill their toh.

bʌt ðɪs? ðiz skæɾɝd ən bɹoʊkən ɹɛtʃəz? pipəl u dɪdn stæn ʌp fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz, hu bɛɡd, hu dɪdnt noʊ haʊ tə sɝvaɪv ɔf ðə lænd? tə noʊ ðət ðiz wɝ əɹ ænsɛstɝz wɑz ə ʃeɪm ʃi nɪɹli kəd nɑt bɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd ðət ɹænd ælθɹ hæd nɑt ɹɪvil ðɪs pæs tə ði il.

But this? These scattered and broken wretches? People who didn't stand up for themselves, who begged, who didn't know how to survive off the land? To know that these were her ancestors was a shame she nearly could not bear. It was good that Rand al'Thor had not revealed this past to the Aiel.

kəd ʃi fli? ɹʌn fɹəm ðə plɑzə ən si noʊ mɔɹ? ɪf ɪt ɡɹu ɛni wɝs, ðə ʃeɪm wəɾ oʊvɝwɛlm hɝ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi nu ðət ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ aʊt, naʊ ðət ʃid bɪɡʌn.

Could she flee? Run from the plaza and see no more? If it grew any worse, the shame would overwhelm her. Unfortunately, she knew that there was only one way out, now that she'd begun.

ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ʃi tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd.

Gritting her teeth, she took a step forward.

ʃi wɑz tɑvə, fɔɹtin jɪɹz oʊld ən skɹimɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪɾ əz ʃi ɹæn fɹəm əɹ bɝnɪŋ haʊs.

She was Tava, fourteen years old and screaming in the night as she ran from her burning house.

ði ɪntaɪɝ væli - ɹɪli ə kænjən, wɪð stip saɪdz - wɑz ɪn fleɪmz. ɛvɹi bɪldɪŋ ɪn ðə flɛdʒlɪŋ hoʊl hæd bɪn sɛɾ əfaɪɹ. naɪtmɛɹɪʃ kɹitʃɝz, wɪð sɪnwəs nɛks ən waɪd wɪŋz, flæpt ɪn ðə naɪɾ əbʌv, bɛɹɪŋ ɹaɪɾɝz wɪð baʊz, spɪɹz, ən stʃɹeɪnʒ nu wɛpənz ðət meɪɾ ə hɪsɪŋ saʊnd wən ðeɪ faɪɝd.

The entire valley - really a canyon, with steep sides - was in flames. Every building in the fledgling hold had been set afire. Nightmarish creatures, with sinuous necks and wide wings, flapped in the night above, bearing riders with bows, spears, and strange new weapons that made a hissing sound when they fired.

tɑvə kɹaɪd, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ fæmli, bʌt ðə hoʊld wɑz ə mæs ə keɪɑs ən kənfjuʒən. səm fju il wɔɹiɝz ɹɪzɪstɪd, bʌɾ ɛniwʌn u ɹeɪzd ə spɪɹ fɛl moʊməns leɪɾɝ, kɪl baɪ æɹoʊ əɹ baɪ wʌn ə ði ɪnvɪzəbəl ʃɑts fɹəm ðə nu wɛpənz.

Tava cried, searching for her family, but the hold was a mass of chaos and confusion. Some few Aiel warriors resisted, but anyone who raised a spear fell moments later, killed by arrow or by one of the invisible shots from the new weapons.

ən il mæn fɛl bɪfɔɹ hɝ, kɔɹps ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ædvɪʃm hæd bɪn ɪz neɪm, ə stoʊn dɔɡ. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju səsaɪəɾiz wɪtʃ stɪl meɪnteɪn ən aɪdɛntəɾi. moʊst wɔɹiɝz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɛl tə ə səsaɪəɾi; ðeɪ meɪd bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz ə ðoʊz wɪð hum ðeɪ kæmpt. ɔl tu ɔfən, ðoʊz kæmps wɝ skæɾɝd ɛniweɪ.

An Aiel man fell before her, corpse rolling on the ground. Tadvishm had been his name, a Stone Dog. It was one of the few societies which still maintained an identity. Most warriors no longer held to a society; they made brothers and sisters of those with whom they camped. All too often, those camps were scattered anyway.

ðɪs hoʊld wɑz tə hæv bɪn dɪfɹənt, sikɹət, dip wɪðɪn ðə weɪst. haʊ hæd ðɛɹ ɛnəmiz faʊn ðɛm?

This hold was to have been different, secret, deep within the Waste. How had their enemies found them?

ə tʃaɪld ʌv oʊnli tu jɪɹz wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ. ʃi dæʃt tə hɪm, snætʃɪŋ ɪm fɹəm wɛɹ i leɪ nɪɹ ðə fleɪmz. ðɛɹ hoʊmz bɝnd. ðə wʊd hæd bɪn skævənʒd wɪð dɪfəkəlti fɹəm ðə maʊntənz ɑn ði istɝn ɛdʒ ə ðə weɪst.

A child of only two years was crying. She dashed to him, snatching him from where he lay near the flames. Their homes burned. The wood had been scavenged with difficulty from the mountains on the eastern edge of the Waste.

ʃi hɛl ðə tʃaɪl kloʊs ən ɹæn təwɔɹd ðə dipɝ ɹisɛsəz ə ðə kænjən. wɛɹ wɑz əɹ fɑðɝ?

She held the child close and ran toward the deeper recesses of the canyon. Where was her father?

wɪð ə sʌɾən wuʃ ə saʊnd, wʌn ə ðə naɪtmɛɹɪʃ kɹitʃɝz lændəd bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ðə bɝst ʌv wɪn meɪkɪŋ əɹ skɝt flæp. ə fɪɹsəm wɔɹiɝ sæɾ əpɑn ðə kɹitʃɝz bæk, hɛlmət laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ən ɪnsɛkt, mændəbəlz ʃɑɹp ən dʒæɡd. hi loʊɝɾ ɪz hɪsɪŋ stæf təwɔɹd hɝ. ʃi kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn tɛɹɝ, hʌɾəlɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə kɹaɪɪŋ tʃaɪld ən kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz.

With a sudden whoosh of sound, one of the nightmarish creatures landed before her, the burst of wind making her skirt flap. A fearsome warrior sat upon the creature's back, helmet like that of an insect, mandibles sharp and jagged. He lowered his hissing staff toward her. She cried out in terror, huddling around the crying child and closing her eyes.

ðə hɪsɪŋ saʊnd nɛvɝ keɪm. əɾ ə ɡɹʌn ən ə sʌɾən skɹitʃ fɹəm ðə sɝpəntaɪn bist, ʃi lʊkt ʌp ən sɔ ə fɪɡjɝ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð ði aʊtləndɝ. ðə faɪɹlaɪt ʃoʊd ðə feɪs ə hɝ fɑðɝ, klin-ʃeɪvən əz ði oʊl tʃɹədɪʃənz dɪkteɪɾəd. ðə bis bɪniθ ðə tu mɛn lɝtʃt, θɹoʊɪŋ boʊθ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

The hissing sound never came. At a grunt and a sudden screech from the serpentine beast, she looked up and saw a figure struggling with the outlander. The firelight showed the face of her father, clean-shaven as the old traditions dictated. The beast beneath the two men lurched, throwing both to the ground.

ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ, hɝ fɑðɝ ɹoʊz, hoʊldɪŋ ði ɪnveɪɾɝz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ɪts lɛŋθ steɪn dɑɹk. ði ɪnveɪɾɝ dɪd nɑt muv, ən bɪhaɪn əm ðə bis lɛpt ɪndə ði ɛɹ, haʊlɪŋ. tɑvə lʊkt ʌp, ən sɔ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk. ði ɪnveɪɾɝz wɝ wɪθdʒɹɔɪŋ, livɪŋ ə bɹoʊkən pipəl wɪð bɝnɪŋ hoʊmz.

A few moments later, her father rose, holding the invader's sword in his hands, its length stained dark. The invader did not move, and behind them the beast leaped into the air, howling. Tava looked up, and saw that it was following the rest of the pack. The invaders were withdrawing, leaving a broken people with burning homes.

ʃi lʊk daʊn əɡɛn. ðə sin hɔɹəfaɪd hɝ; soʊ mɛni bɑɾiz, dɑz-ɛnz, leɪ bliɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ði ɪnveɪɾɝ ðəɾ əɹ fɑðɝ hæd kɪld əpɪɹd tə bi ði oʊnli ɛnəmi ðət hæd fɔlən.

She looked down again. The scene horrified her; so many bodies, doz-ens, lay bleeding on the ground. The invader that her father had killed appeared to be the only enemy that had fallen.

"ɡæðɝ sænd!" hɝ fɑðɝ - ɹoʊən - ɹɔɹd. "kwɛntʃ ðə fleɪmz!"

"Gather sand!" her father - Rowahn - roared. "Quench the flames!"

tɔl - ivən fəɹ ən il - wɪð stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ɹɛd hɛɹ, hi wɔɹ ði oʊl kloʊðɪŋ ə bɹaʊn ən tæn, buts taɪd haɪ tə hɪz niz. ðət kloʊðɪŋ mɑɹkt wʌn əz il, ðɛɹfɔɹ mɛni hæɾ əbændən ɪt. biɪŋ noʊn əz il mɛn dɛθ.

Tall - even for an Aiel - with striking red hair, he wore the old clothing of brown and tan, boots tied high to his knees. That clothing marked one as Aiel, therefore many had abandoned it. Being known as Aiel meant death.

hɝ fɑðɝ hæɾ ɪnhɛɹəɾɪd ɪz kloʊðɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɡɹændfɑðɝ, əlɔŋ wɪð ə tʃɑɹdʒ. fɑloʊ ði oʊld weɪz. ɹɪmɛmbɝ dʒiɾoʊ. faɪɾ ən meɪnteɪn ɑnɝ. ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn ɪn ðə hoʊl fəɹ oʊnli ə fju deɪz, ði ʌðɝz lɪsənd wən i jɛl fəɹ əm tə pʊɾ aʊt ðə faɪɝz. tɑvə ɹɪtɝn ðə tʃaɪl tə ə ɡɹeɪtfəl mʌðɝ ən ðən hɛlpt ɡæðɝ sæn ən dɝt.

Her father had inherited his clothing from his grandfather, along with a charge. Follow the old ways. Remember ji'e'toh. Fight and maintain honor. Though he had been in the hold for only a few days, the others listened when he yelled for them to put out the fires. Tava returned the child to a grateful mother and then helped gather sand and dirt.

ə fju aʊɝz leɪɾɝ, ə taɪɝɾ ən blʌɾid pipəl ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kænjən, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wɪð dʌl aɪz wʌt ðeɪ hæd wɝk fəɹ mʌnθs tə bɪld. ɪt hæd bɪn waɪpt aʊɾ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl naɪt. hɝ fɑðɝ stɪl kæɹid ðə sɔɹd. hi juzd ɪt tə dɝɛk ðə pipəl. səm ə ði oʊld wʌnz sɛd ðəɾ ə sɔɹd wɑz bæd lʌk, bʌt waɪ wəd ðeɪ seɪ ðæt? ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə wɛpən.

A few hours later, a tired and bloodied people gathered in the center of the canyon, regarding with dull eyes what they had worked for months to build. It had been wiped out in a single night. Her father still carried the sword. He used it to direct the people. Some of the old ones said that a sword was bad luck, but why would they say that? It was only a weapon.

"wi mʌst ɹibɪld," hɝ fɑðɝ sɛd, sɝveɪɪŋ ðə ɹɛkədʒ.

"We must rebuild," her father said, surveying the wreckage.

"ɹibɪld?" sɛɾ ə sʊt-steɪn mæn. "ðə ɡɹænɛɹi wɑz ðə fɝs tə bɝn! ðəɹ ɪz noʊ fud!"

"Rebuild?" said a soot-stained man. "The granary was the first to burn! There is no food!"

"wi wɪl sɝvaɪv," hɝ fɑðɝ sɛd. "wi kən muv dipɝ ɪndə ðə weɪst."

"We will survive," her father said. "We can move deeper into the Waste."

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊwɛɹ ɛls tə ɡoʊ!" ənʌðɝ mæn sɛd. "ðə ɹeɪvən ɛmpaɪɝ əz sɛnt wɝd tə ðə fɑɹ wʌnz, ən ðeɪ hʌn əs ət ði istɝn bɔɹɾɝ!"

"There is nowhere else to go!" another man said. "The Raven Empire has sent word to the Far Ones, and they hunt us at the eastern border!"

"ðeɪ faɪn əs wɛnɛvɝ wi ɡæðɝ!" ənʌðɝ kɹaɪd.

"They find us whenever we gather!" another cried.

"ɪɾ ɪz ə pʌnɪʃmənt!" hɝ fɑðɝ sɛd. "bʌt wi mʌst ɛndʒjʊɹ!"

"It is a punishment!" her father said. "But we must endure!"

ðə pipəl lʊkt ət hɪm. ðɛn, ɪn pɛɹz əɹ smɔl ɡɹups, ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə wɔk əweɪ.

The people looked at him. Then, in pairs or small groups, they began to walk away.

"weɪt," hɝ fɑðɝ sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hænd. "wi mʌst steɪ təɡɛðɝ, kip faɪɾɪŋ! ðə klæn - "

"Wait," her father said, raising his hand. "We must stay together, keep fighting! The clan - "

"wi ɑɹ nɑɾ ə klæn," ən æʃən mæn sɛd. "aɪ kən sɝvaɪv bɛɾɝ ɑn maɪ oʊn. noʊ mɔɹ faɪɾɪŋ. ðeɪ biɾ əs wən wi faɪt."

"We are not a clan," an ashen man said. "I can survive better on my own. No more fighting. They beat us when we fight."

hɝ fɑðɝ loʊɝd ðə sɔɹd, ɪts tɪp hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. tɑvə muvd ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm, wɝiɾ əz ʃi wɑtʃt ði ʌðɝz wɔk ðɛɹ weɪz ɪndə ðə naɪt. ði ɛɹ wɑz stɪl θɪk wɪð smoʊk. ðə dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ il wɝ ʃædoʊz, mɛltɪŋ ɪndə dɑɹknəs, laɪk swɝlz ə dʌs bloʊn ɑn ðə wɪnd. ðeɪ dɪdn pɔz tə bɛɹi ðɛɹ dɛd.

Her father lowered the sword, its tip hitting the ground. Tava moved up beside him, worried as she watched the others walk their ways into the night. The air was still thick with smoke. The departing Aiel were shadows, melting into darkness, like swirls of dust blown on the wind. They didn't pause to bury their dead.

hɝ fɑðɝ baʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ən dʒɹɑp ðə sɔɹd tə ði æʃ-kʌvɝd ɡɹaʊnd.

Her father bowed his head and dropped the sword to the ash-covered ground.

ðəɹ wɝ tɛɹz ɪn eɪvinhəz aɪz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʃeɪm ət kɹaɪɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɪs tʃɹædʒəɾi. ʃi hæd fɪɹd ðə tʃɹuθ, ən ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dɪnaɪ ɪt.

There were tears in Aviendha's eyes. There was no shame at crying over this tragedy. She had feared the truth, and she could no longer deny it.

ðoʊz hæd bɪn sintʃæn ɹeɪɾɝz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ɹeɪkən. ðə ɹeɪvən ɛmpaɪɝ, ðə laɪtmeɪkɝz fɹəm əɹ fɝs vɪʒən, wɝ ðə sintʃæn - ən ðeɪ hædn ɪɡzɪstəɾ əntɪl ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɝən eɪdʒ, wən ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz hæd kɹɔs ði oʊʃənz. .

Those had been Seanchan raiders, riding atop raken. The Raven Empire, the Lightmakers from her first vision, were the Seanchan - and they hadn't existed until the middle of the current Age, when Artur Hawkwings armies had crossed the oceans. .

ʃi wɑz nɑt siɪŋ ðə dip pæst ə hɝ pipəl. ʃi wɑz siɪŋ ðɛɹ fjutʃɝ.

She was not seeing the deep past of her people. She was seeing their future.

hɝ fɝs taɪm θɹu ðə pɪlɝz, itʃ stɛp hæd teɪkən əɹ bækwɝd, muvɪŋ əɹ θɹu taɪm təwɔɹd ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət ðɪs taɪm, ðə vɪʒənz hæd stɑɹɾəd əɾ ə dɪstən pɔɪn ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ, ən wɝ wɝkɪŋ bæk təwɔɹɾ əɹ deɪ, itʃ vɪʒən dʒʌmpɪŋ bæk ə dʒɛnɝeɪʃən əɹ tu. tɪɹz stʃɹikɪŋ əɹ feɪs, ʃi tʊk ðə nɛkst stɛp.

Her first time through the pillars, each step had taken her backward, moving her through time toward the Age of Legends. It appeared that this time, the visions had started at a distant point in the future, and were working back toward her day, each vision jumping back a generation or two. Tears streaking her face, she took the next step.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 49

kɔɹɾ ə ðə sʌn


Court of the Sun

ʃi wɑz læɾəlɪn, waɪz wʌn ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il. haʊ ʃi wɪʃt ðət ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə lɝn tə tʃænəl. ðət wɑz ə ʃeɪmfəl θɔt, wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ ə tælənt wʌn dɪd nɑt hæv, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt dɪnaɪ ɪt.

She was Ladalin, Wise One of the Taardad Aiel. How she wished that she had been able to learn to channel. That was a shameful thought, wishing for a talent one did not have, but she could not deny it.

ʃi sæɾ ɪn ðə tɛnt, filɪŋ ɹɪɡɹɛtfəl. ɪf ʃid bɪn eɪbəl tə wɝk wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, pɝhæps ʃi cʊɾə dʌn mɔɹ tə hɛlp ðə wundəd. ʃi cʊɾə ɹɪmeɪn jʌŋ tə liɾ əɹ klæn, ən pɝhæps əɹ boʊnz wəd nɑɾ eɪk soʊ. oʊld eɪdʒ wɑz ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən wən ðəɹ wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ tə du.

She sat in the tent, feeling regretful. If she'd been able to work with the One Power, perhaps she could have done more to help the wounded. She could have remained young to lead her clan, and perhaps her bones would not ache so. Old age was a frustration when there was so much to do.

ðə tɛnt wɔlz ɹʌsəld əz ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ klæn tʃifs sɛɾəld daʊn. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn ʌðɝ waɪz wʌn ɪn ðə ɹum, mɔɹə ʌv ðə ɡoʊʃin il. ʃi kəd nɑt tʃænəl iðɝ. ðə sintʃæn wɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dɪtɝmənd wən ɪt keɪm tə kɪlɪŋ əɹ kæptʃɝɪŋ ɔl il - meɪl əɹ fimeɪl - hu ʃoʊɾ ɛni tælənt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

The tent walls rustled as the remaining clan chiefs settled down. There was only one other Wise One in the room, Mora of the Goshien Aiel. She could not channel either. The Seanchan were particularly determined when it came to killing or capturing all Aiel - male or female - who showed any talent with the One Power.

ɪt wɑz ə sɑɹi ɡɹup ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ðə tɛnt. ə wʌn-ɑɹm jʌŋ soʊlʒɝ ɛntɝd wɪð ə wɔɹm bɹeɪziɝ ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛm, ðən ɹitʃɹiɾəd. læɾəlɪnz mʌðɝ hæd spoʊkən ə ðə deɪz wən ðəɹ hæd stɪl bɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn tə də sətʃ wɝk. hæd ðəɹ ɹɪli bɪn il, mæn əɹ meɪɾən, hu hæd nɑt bɪn niɾəd fəɹ ðə wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn?

It was a sorry group gathered in the tent. A one-armed young soldier entered with a warm brazier and set it in the middle of them, then retreated. Ladalin's mother had spoken of the days when there had still been gai'shain to do such work. Had there really been Aiel, man or Maiden, who had not been needed for the war against the Seanchan?

læɾəlɪn ɹitʃt fɔɹwɝd tə wɔɹm əɹ hænz ət ðə bɹeɪziɝ, fɪŋɡɝz nɑɾɪd wɪð eɪdʒ. ʃid hɛld ə spɪɹ əz ə jʌŋ wʊmən; moʊst wɪmən dɪd, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ mɛɹid. haʊ kəɾ ə wʊmən ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd wən ðə sintʃæn juz fimeɪl soʊlʒɝz ən ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn wɪð sətʃ ɪfɛktɪvnəs?

Ladalin reached forward to warm her hands at the brazier, fingers knotted with age. She'd held a spear as a young woman; most women did, before they married. How could a woman remain behind when the Seanchan used female soldiers and their damane with such effectiveness?

ʃid hɝd stɔɹiz əbaʊɾ əɹ mʌðɝ ən ɡɹieɪtmɑðɝz deɪz, bʌt ðeɪ siɹn ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl. ðə wɔɹ wɑz ɔl læɾəlɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. hɝ fɝs mɛmɹiz əz ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl wɝ ə ði ɑlməθ stʃɹaɪks. hɝ juθ hæd bɪn spɛn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ʃi hæd fɔɾ ɪn ðə bæɾəlz foʊkəst ɝaʊn ðə læn ðət hæd bɪn noʊn əz tiɹ.

She'd heard stories about her mother and greatmother's days, but they seerned incredible. The war was all Ladalin had ever known. Her first memories as a little girl were of the Almoth strikes. Her youth had been spent training. She had fought in the battles focused around the land that had been known as Tear.

læɾəlɪn hæd mɛɹiɾ ən ɹeɪz tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌt hæd foʊkəst ɛvɹi bɹɛθ ɑn ðə kɑnflɪkt. il əɹ sintʃæn. boʊθ nu ðæt, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, oʊnli wʌn ə ðə tu wəd ɹɪmeɪn.

Ladalin had married and raised children, but had focused every breath on the conflict. Aiel or Seanchan. Both knew that, eventually, only one of the two would remain.

ɪt wɑz lʊkɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ laɪk ði il wəd bi ðə wʌnz fɔɹst aʊt. ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ dɪfɝəns bɪtwin əɹ deɪ ən əɹ mʌðɝz deɪ. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd nɑt spoʊkən ə feɪljɝ; læɾəlɪnz laɪftaɪm wɑz fɪld wɪð maɪlstoʊnz ʌv wɪðdʒɹɔəl ən ɹitʃɹit.

It was looking more and more like the Aiel would be the ones forced out. That was another difference between her day and her mother's day. Her mother had not spoken of failure; Ladalin's lifetime was filled with milestones of withdrawal and retreat.

ði ʌðɝz simd əbzɔɹbd ɪn ðɛɹ θɔts. θɹi klæn tʃifs ən tu waɪz wʌnz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə twɛnti-tu. haɪlənd wɪnz sip θɹu ðə tɛn flæps, tʃɪlɪŋ əɹ bæk. tɑmɑv wɑz ðə læs tə ɝaɪv. hi lʊkt əz oʊld əz ʃi fɛlt, hɪz feɪs skɑɹɾ ən ɪz lɛft aɪ lɔst ɪn bæɾəl. hi sæt daʊn ɑn ðə ɹɑk. ði il noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kæɹid ɹʌɡz əɹ kʊʃənz. oʊnli ði ɛsɛntʃəlz kəd bi tʃɹænspɔɹɾəd.

The others seemed absorbed in their thoughts. Three clan chiefs and two Wise Ones. They were all that remained of the Council of Twenty-Two. Highland winds seeped through the tent flaps, chilling her back. Tamaav was the last to arrive. He looked as old as she felt, his face scarred and his left eye lost in battle. He sat down on the rock. The Aiel no longer carried rugs or cushions. Only the essentials could be transported.

"ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz fɔlən," hi sɛd. "maɪ skaʊts ɪnfɔɹmd mi nɑɾ ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ. aɪ tʃɹʌs ðɛɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən." hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə blʌn mæn, ən ə ɡʊd fɹɛn tə hɝ hʌzbənd, hu hæd fɔlən læs jɪɹ.

"The White Tower has fallen," he said. "My scouts informed me not an hour ago. I trust their information." He had always been a blunt man, and a good friend to her husband, who had fallen last year.

"ðɛn wɪð ɪt ɡoʊz əɹ læs hoʊp," sɛd tɑkɑi, ðə jʌŋɡəst ə ðə klæn tʃifs. hi wɑz ðə θɝd tʃif ə ðə maɪæɡoʊmə ɪn əz mɛni jɪɹz.

"Then with it goes our last hope," said Takai, the youngest of the clan chiefs. He was the third chief of the Miagoma in as many years.

"spik nɑt soʊ," læɾəlɪn sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz hoʊp."

"Speak not so," Ladalin said. "There is always hope."

"ðeɪ hæv pʊʃt əs ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðiz kɝs maʊntənz," tɑkɑi sɛd. "ðə ʃiæn ən ðə dɛɹn ɑɹ noʊ mɔɹ. ðət livz oʊnli faɪv klænz, ən wʌn ə ðoʊz ɪz bɹoʊkən ən skæɾɝd. wəɹ biɾən, læɾəlɪn."

"They have pushed us all the way to these cursed mountains," Takai said. "The Shiande and the Daryne are no more. That leaves only five clans, and one of those is broken and scattered. We are beaten, Ladalin."

tɑmɑv saɪd. ʃiɾ əv leɪn ə bɹaɪɾəl ɹiθ əɾ ɪz fit, hæd ðə jɪɹz bɪn ɝliɝ ən ðə taɪmz dɪfɹənt. hɝ klæn niɾəd ə tʃif. hɝ sʌn stɪl θɔt tə bɪkʌm ðə wʌn, bʌt wɪð ðə ɹisən sintʃæn kæptʃɝ ə ɹɪɾiən, ðə klænz wɝ ənsɝɾən haʊ tə tʃuz nu liɾɝz.

Tamaav sighed. She'd have lain a bridal wreath at his feet, had the years been earlier and the times different. Her clan needed a chief. Her son still thought to become the one, but with the recent Seanchan capture of Rhuidean, the clans were uncertain how to choose new leaders.

"wi mʌst ɹitʃɹiɾ ɪndə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd," mɔɹə sɛɾ ɪn əɹ sɑft, meɪtʃɹənli vɔɪs. "æn sik pɛnəns fəɹ əɹ sɪnz."

"We must retreat into the Three-fold Land," Mora said in her soft, matronly voice. "And seek penance for our sins."

"wʌt sɪnz?" tɑkɑi snæpt.

"What sins?" Takai snapped.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑntəd pis," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd.

"The Dragon wanted peace," she replied.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən lɛft ʌs!" tɑkɑi sɛd. "aɪ ɹəfjuz tə fɑloʊ ðə mɛmɹi ʌv ə mæn maɪ ɡɹeɪtfɑðɝz bɛɹli nu. wi meɪd noʊ oʊðz tə fɑloʊ hɪz fulɪʃ pækt. wi - "

"The Dragon left us!" Takai said. "I refuse to follow the memory of a man my greatfathers barely knew. We made no oaths to follow his foolish pact. We - "

"pis, tɑkɑi," dʒɔɹʃəm sɛd. ðə læst ə ðə θɹi klæn tʃifs wɑz ə smɔl, hɔk-feɪs mæn wɪð səm ændɔɝən blʌɾ ɪn ɪm fɹəm ɪz ɡɹeɪtfə-θɝ. "oʊnli ðə θɹi- foʊld læn hoʊlz ɛni hoʊp fəɹ ʌs, naʊ. ðə wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪvənz əz bɪn lɔst."

"Peace, Takai," Jorshem said. The last of the three clan chiefs was a small, hawk-faced man with some Andoran blood in him from his greatfa-ther. "Only the Three- fold Land holds any hope for us, now. The war against the Ravens has been lost."

ðə tɛn fɛl stɪl.

The tent fell still.

"ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪd hʌn ʌs," tɑkɑi sɛd. "wɛn ðeɪ dɪmændəd sɝɛndɝ, ðeɪ wɔɹn əs əɡɛnst ɹitʃɹit. jə noʊ ðæt. ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪ wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛni pleɪs wɛɹ θɹi il ɡæðɝd."

"They said they'd hunt us," Takai said. "When they demanded surrender, they warned us against retreat. You know that. They Said they would destroy any place where three Aiel gathered."

"wi wɪl nɑt sɝɛndɝ," læɾəlɪn sɛd fɝmli. mɔɹ fɝmli ðən ʃi fɛl tə bi ɑnəst.

"We will not surrender," Ladalin said firmly. More firmly than she felt to be honest.

"sɝɛndɝ wəd meɪk əs ɡeɪʃeɪn" tɑmɑv sɛd. ðeɪ juz ðə wɝd tə min wʌn wɪθaʊɾ ɑnɝ, ðoʊ ðət wɑz nɑt ðə weɪ læɾəlɪnz mʌðɝ hæd juzd ɪt. "læɾəlɪn. wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ ædvaɪs?"

"Surrender would make us gai'shain" Tamaav said. They used the word to mean one without honor, though that was not the way Ladalins mother had used it. "Ladalin. What is your advice?"

ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ lʊkt ət hɝ. ʃi wɑz ə ðə lɪniədʒ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, wʌn ə ðə læs lɪvɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ θɹi laɪnz hæd bɪn kɪld ɔf.

The other four looked at her. She was of the lineage of the Dragon, one of the last living. The other three lines had been killed off.

"ɪf wi bɪkʌm sleɪvz tə ðə sintʃæn, ði il əz ə pipəl wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ," ʃi sɛd. "wi kænɑt wɪn, soʊ wi mʌst ɹitʃɹit. wɪl ɹɪtɝn tə ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ən bɪld ʌp əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ.

"If we become slaves to the Seanchan, the Aiel as a people will be no more," she said. "We cannot win, so we must retreat. We will return to the Three-fold Land and build up our strength.

pɝhæps əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən kən faɪt wɛɹ wi kænɑt."

Perhaps our children can fight where we cannot."

saɪləns əɡɛn. ðeɪ ɔl nu hɝ wɝdz tə bi ɑptəmɪstɪk ət bɛst. æftɝ dɛkeɪdz ʌv wɔɹ, ði il wɝ ə bɛɹ fɹækʃən ə ðə nʌmbɝ ðeɪ hæd wʌns bɪn.

Silence again. They all knew her words to be optimistic at best. After decades of war, the Aiel were a bare fraction of the number they had once been.

sintʃæn tʃænlɝz wɝ bɹuɾəl ɪn ðɛɹ ɪfɛktɪvnəs. ðoʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz ən dʒɹæɡən blʌɾɪd juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn bæɾəl, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. ðoʊz kɝst æɾəm itʃ tʃænlɝ ði il lɔs tə kæptʃɝ wɑz ɪvɛntʃəwəli tɝn əɡɛns ðɛm.

Seanchan channelers were brutal in their effectiveness. Though the Wise Ones and Dragon Blooded used the One Power in battle, it was not enough. Those cursed a'dam\ Each channeler the Aiel lost to capture was eventually turned against them.

ðə ɹil tɝnɪŋ pɔɪn ɪn ðə wɔɹ hæd bɪn ði ɛntʃɹi ʌv ði ʌðɝ neɪʃənz. æftɝ ðæt, ðə sintʃæn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə siz wɛtləndɝ pipəlz ən kʌl mɔɹ tʃænlɝz fɹəm ðɛɹ ɹæŋks. ðə ɹeɪvənz wɝ ənstɑpəbəl; naʊ ðət tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd fɔlən, ɛvɹi ɹɛlm ɪn ðə wɛtlænz wɑz sʌbʒɪkt tə ðə sintʃæn. oʊnli ðə blæk taʊɝ stɪl fɔt, ðoʊ ði æʃəmən dɪd soʊ ɪn sikɹət, əz ðɛɹ fɔɹtʃɹəs hæd fɔlən jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ.

The real turning point in the war had been the entry of the other nations. After that, the Seanchan had been able to seize wetlander peoples and cull more channelers from their ranks. The Ravens were unstoppable; now that Tar Valon had fallen, every realm in the wetlands was subject to the Seanchan. Only the Black Tower still fought, though the Asha'man did so in secret, as their fortress had fallen years before.

il kəd nɑt faɪɾ ɪn sikɹət. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɑnɝ tə ðæt. ʌv kɔɹs, wʌɾ ɑnɝ mæɾɝ naʊ?

Aiel could not fight in secret. There was no honor to that. Of course, what did honor matter now?

æftɝ dɛθs nʌmbɝɪŋ ɪn ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz? æftɝ ðə bɝnɪŋ ə kɛɹhin ən ðə skaʊɝɪŋ oʊfɪljən? ɪt hæd bɪn twɛnti jɪɹz sɪns ðə sintʃæn hæd ɡeɪn ði ændɔɝən wɔɹ məʃinz. ði il hæd bɪn tʌmbəlɪŋ təwɔɹd dɪfit fəɹ dɛkeɪdz; ɪt wɑz ə tɛstəmən tə ðɛɹ təneɪʃəs neɪtʃɝ ðət ðeɪ hæd læstəd soʊ lɔŋ.

After deaths numbering in the hundreds of thousands? After the burning of Cairhien and the scouring ofIllian? It had been twenty years since the Seanchan had gained the Andoran war machines. The Aiel had been tumbling toward defeat for decades; it was a testament to their tenacious nature that they had lasted so long.

"ðɪs ɪz ɪz fɔlt," tɑkɑi sɛd, stɪl lʊkɪŋ sʌlən. "ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn cʊɾə lɛɾ əs tə ɡlɔɹi, bʌɾ i əbændən ʌs."

"This is his fault," Takai said, still looking sullen. "The Car'a'carn could have led us to glory, but he abandoned us."

"hɪz fɔlt?" læɾəlɪn sɛd, ʌndɝstændɪŋ - pɝhæps fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm- waɪ ðət steɪtmənt wɑz ɹɔŋ. "noʊ. il teɪk ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ðɛm-sɛlvz. ðɪs ɪz əɹ fɔlt, ən nɑt ðəɾ ə maɪ dɪstənt ɡɹeɪtfɑðɝ. wɪv fɝɡɑɾən u wi ɑɹ. wəɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɑnɝ."

"His fault?" Ladalin said, understanding - perhaps for the first time- why that statement was wrong. "No. Aiel take responsibility for them-selves. This is our fault, and not that of my distant greatfather. We have forgotten who we are. We are without honor."

"aʊɝ ɑnɝ wɑz teɪkən fɹəm ʌs," tɑkɑi sɛd, saɪɪŋ əz i stʊd. "pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪndid.

"Our honor was taken from us," Takai said, sighing as he stood. "People of the Dragon indeed.

wʌɾ ɪz ðə ɡʊɾ ə biɪŋ ɪz pipəl? wi wɝ dʒɹæftɪd tə bi ə spɪɹ, ðə lɛdʒənz seɪ, fɔɹdʒd ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. hi juzd ʌs, ðən kæst əs əweɪ. wʌɾ ɪz ə dɪskɑɹɾɪd spɪɹ tə du, bʌt ɡoʊ tə wɔɹ?"

What is the good of being his people? We were drafted to be a spear, the legends say, forged in the Three-fold Land. He used us, then cast us away. What is a discarded spear to do, but go to war?"

wʌɾ ɪndid, læɾəlɪn θɔt. ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd dɪmændəd pis, θɪŋkɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt wəd bɹɪŋ hæpinəs tə ði il. bʌt haʊ kəd ðeɪ bi hæpi, wən ðə laɪt-kɝst sintʃæn wɝ ɪn ðə lænd? hɝ heɪtʃɹəɾ ə ði ɪnveɪɾɝz ɹæn dip.

What indeed, Ladalin thought. The Dragon had demanded peace, thinking that it would bring happiness to the Aiel. But how could they be happy, when the Light-cursed Seanchan were in the land? Her hatred of the invaders ran deep.

pɝhæps ðət heɪtʃɹəd hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd ði il. ʃi lɪsən tə ðə wɪn haʊl əz tɑkɑi stɔk fɹəm ðə tɛnt. ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ ði il wəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. ɪf ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ æksɛpt pis ðɛmsɛlvz, ɪt sim ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə hæv ɪt fɔɹst əpɑn ðɛm.

Perhaps that hatred had destroyed the Aiel. She listened to the wind howl as Takai stalked from the tent. On the morrow the Aiel would return to the Three-fold Land. If they would not accept peace themselves, it seemed they would have to have it forced upon them.

eɪvinhə tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp fɔɹwɝd. ʃid nɪɹli ɹitʃt ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə kɑləmz, ən ʃɑɹdz ə laɪt spɑɹkəld ɝaʊn hɝ.

Aviendha took another step forward. She'd nearly reached the very center of the columns, and shards of light sparkled around her.

hɝ tɪɹz floʊd fɹili naʊ. ʃi fɛlt laɪk ə tʃaɪld. biɪŋ læɾəlɪn hæd bɪn wɝs ðən ði ʌðɝz, fəɹ ɪn hɝ, eɪvinhə hæd sin hɪns ə tʃɹu il weɪz, bʌt kɝʌptɪd, əz ɪf tə meɪk mɑkɝi. ðə wʊmən hæd θɔɾ ʌv wɔɹ ən əsoʊsieɪɾəd ɪt wɪð ɑnɝ, bʌt hædn ʌndɝstʊd wʌɾ ɑnɝ wɑz. noʊ ɡeɪʃeɪn? ɹitʃɹit? ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ mɛnʃən ə toʊ. ðɪs wɑz bæɾəl stʃɹɪp kəmplitli ʌv pɔɪn əɹ ɹizən.

Her tears flowed freely now. She felt like a child. Being Ladalin had been worse than the others, for in her, Aviendha had seen hints of true Aiel ways, but corrupted, as if to make mockery. The woman had thought of war and associated it with honor, but hadn't understood what honor was. No gai'shain? Retreat? There had been no mention of toh. This was battle stripped completely of point or reason.

waɪ faɪt? fəɹ læɾəlɪn, ɪt hæd bɪn əbaʊt heɪtʃɹəɾ ə ðə sintʃæn. ðəɹ wɑz wɔɹ kəz ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn wɔɹ.

Why fight? For Ladalin, it had been about hatred of the Seanchan. There was war because there had always been war.

haʊ? haʊ hæd ðɪs hæpən tə ði il?

How? How had this happened to the Aiel?

eɪvinhə tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd.

Aviendha took a step forward.

ʃi wɑz ɑnkɑlə, meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ. ʃi wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡɪv ðə spɪɹ ʌp ən mɛɹi, dʒʌst əz əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ən əɹ mʌðɝz mʌðɝ bɪfɔɹ hɝ. bʌt naʊ wɑz ðə taɪm tə faɪt.

She was Oncala, Maiden of the Spear. She would eventually give the spear up and marry, just as her mother had and her mother's mother before her. But now was the time to fight.

ʃi stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn, hɝ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ kæɹiɪŋ ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən tə ənaʊns əɹ lɪniədʒ. nɛks tə ɑnkɑlə wɑz ðə mæn fəɹ hum ʃi wəd laɪkli ɡɪv ʌp əɹ spɪɹz.

She strode through the streets of Caemlyn, her near-sister carrying the banner of the Dragon to announce her lineage. Next to Oncala was the man for whom she would likely give up her spears.

hɛjəl, dɔn ɹʌnɝ, hæd kɪl mɔɹ sintʃæn ðən ɛni ʌv ɪz səsaɪəɾi, ɡeɪnɪŋ mʌtʃ dʒi. hi hæd bɪn ɡɹæntəd pɝmɪʃən tə tʃɹævəl tə ɹɪɾiən læs jɪɹ tə bɪkʌm klæn tʃif.

Hehyal, Dawn Runner, had killed more Seanchan than any of his society, gaining much ji. He had been granted permission to travel to Rhuidean last year to become clan chief.

ɹɪɾiən. ðə sɪɾi wɑz bɪsidʒ baɪ sintʃæn. ɑnkɑlə snɪɹd. ʃɔn-tʃæn hæd noʊ ɑnɝ. ðeɪ hæd bɪn toʊl ðət ɹɪɾiən wɑz ə pleɪs fəɹ pis. ði il dɪd nɑɾ əsɔl ðə pæləs ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ.

Rhuidean. The city was besieged by Seanchan. Oncala sneered. Sean-chan had no honor. They had been told that Rhuidean was a place for peace. The Aiel did not assault the palace in Ebou Dar.

ðə sintʃə ʃəd nɑɾ ətæk ɹɪɾiən.

The Seancha should not attack Rhuidean.

ðeɪ wɝ lɪzɝdz. ɪt wɑz ə sɔɹs ə kɑnstən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ðæt, æftɝ di-keɪdz ʌv wɔɹ, ðə bæɾəl laɪnz ɹɪmeɪnd nɪɹli ðə seɪm əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn æftɝ əɹ ɡɹeɪtfɑðɝ wɛn tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

They were lizards. It was a source of constant frustration that, after de-cades of war, the battle lines remained nearly the same as they had been after her greatfather went to Shayol Ghul.

ʃi ən hɛjəl wɝ əkʌmpənid baɪ tu θaʊzən spɪɹz əz ə ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ɑnɝ. kwin tɑlænə nu tə ɪkspɛk ðɛm, ən soʊ ðə waɪɾ ændɔɝən pæləs ɡeɪts wɝ oʊpən. hɛjəl weɪv fəɹ fɪfti spɪɹz, pɹisəlɛktɪd, tə wɔk wɪð əm θɹu ðə faɪn hɔlz. lʌʃnəs əbaʊndəd hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs.

She and Hehyal were accompanied by two thousand spears as a guard of honor. Queen Talana knew to expect them, and so the white Andoran palace gates were open. Hehyal waved for fifty spears, preselected, to walk with them through the fine halls. Lushness abounded here in the palace.

itʃ tæpəstʃɹi, itʃ veɪs, itʃ ɡoʊldən fɹeɪm simd ən ɪnsəl tə ɑnkɑlə. fɔɹɾi jɪɹz ʌv wɔɹ, ən ændɝ hæd nɑt bɪn tʌtʃt. ɪt leɪ seɪf, bæskɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹətɛkʃən ði il dɪfɛns ɡeɪv ðɛm.

Each tapestry, each vase, each golden frame seemed an insult to Oncala. Forty years of war, and Andor had not been touched. It lay safe, basking in the protection the Aiel defense gave them.

wɛl, ændɝ wəd si. ði il hæd ɡɹoʊn stʃɹɔŋɝ θɹu ðɛɹ faɪɾɪŋ. wʌns, ðɛɹ pɹaʊəs hæd bɪn lɛdʒəndɛɹi. naʊ ɪt wɑz ɡɹeɪɾɝ! wən ði il hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə sintʃæn, ðə wɝld wəd si wʌt ði il hæd lɝnd. ðə wɛtlæn ɹulɝz wəd wɪʃ ðeɪ hæd bɪn mɔɹ dʒɛnɝəs.

Well, Andor would see. The Aiel had grown stronger through their fighting. Once, their prowess had been legendary. Now it was greater! When the Aiel had destroyed the Seanchan, the world would see what the Aiel had learned. The wetland rulers would wish they had been more generous.

ðə θɹoʊn ɹum dɔɹz wɝ oʊpən; ɑnkɑlə ən hɛjəl ɛntɝd, livɪŋ ðɛɹ ɛskɔɹt. ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən flu hɪɹ, tu, ə ɹimaɪndɝ ðət ði ændɔɝən ɹɔɪəl laɪn ɔlsoʊ kæɹid ðə lɪniədʒ ə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn. wʌn mɔɹ ɹizən fəɹ ɑnkɑlə tə heɪt ðɛm. ði ændɔɝən noʊbɪləɾi θɔt ðɛmsɛlvz əɹ ikwəlz.

The throne room doors were open; Oncala and Hehyal entered, leaving their escort. The banner of the Dragon flew here, too, a reminder that the Andoran royal line also carried the lineage of the Car'a'carn. One more reason for Oncala to hate them. The Andoran nobility thought themselves her equals.

kwin tɑlænə wɑz ə mɪɾəl-eɪdʒd wʊmən wɪð dip, lʌstʃɹəs ɹɛd hɛɹ. nɑt vɛɹi pɹɪɾi, bʌt vɛɹi ɹiɡəl. ʃi wɑz spikɪŋ kwaɪətli wɪð wʌn ə hɝ ædvaɪzɝz, ən ʃi weɪv fəɹ ði il tə weɪt. ən ɪnsəlt, dɪlɪbɝɪt. ɑnkɑlə fjumd.

Queen Talana was a middle-aged woman with deep, lustrous red hair. Not very pretty, but very regal. She was speaking quietly with one of her advisors, and she waved for the Aiel to wait. An insult, deliberate. Oncala fumed.

faɪnəli, ðeɪ wɝ sʌmən tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. tɑlænəz bɹʌðɝ, hɝ pɹətɛktɝ, stʊd bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪn kɔɹt kloʊðɪŋ - ə vɛst ən koʊt - hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. ɑnkɑlə cʊɾə kɪld ɪm waɪl bɛɹli bɹeɪkɪŋ ə swɛt.

Finally, they were summoned to approach the Lion Throne. Talana's brother, her protector, stood behind her in court clothing - a vest and coat - hand on his sword. Oncala could have killed him while barely breaking a sweat.

"ɑ," kwin tɑlænə sɛd. "ðə tɑɹdæɾ il əɡɛn. jə stɪl kæɹi ðə spɪɹ, ɑnkɑlə?"

"Ah," Queen Talana said. "The Taardad Aiel again. You still carry the spear, Oncala?"

ɑnkɑlə foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ʃi nu ʃi wɑz nɑt ɡʊd wɪð pipəl. wən ʃi spoʊk, ɪnsʌls wɝ tu kɑmən. bɛɾɝ tə lɛt ðə klæn tʃif teɪk ðə lɛd.

Oncala folded her arms, but said nothing. She knew she was not good with people. When she spoke, insults were too common. Better to let the clan chief take the lead.

"aɪ əsum jəɹ hɪɹ tə bɛɡ fəɹ eɪɾ əɡɛn," tɑlænə sɛd.

"I assume you're here to beg for aid again," Talana said.

hɛjəl flʌʃt, ən ɑnkɑlə wɪʃt - fəɹ ə moʊmənt - ʃi hædn lɛft əɹ spɪɹ aʊtsaɪd.

Hehyal flushed, and Oncala wished - for a moment - she hadn't left her spear outside.

"wi hæv sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ju," hɛjəl sɛd, teɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə lɛðɝ paʊtʃ ən hændɪŋ ɪt tə wʌn ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. ðə mæn oʊpən ɪt, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə peɪpɝz ɪnsaɪd. ənʌðɝ ɪnsəlt. mʌs ðeɪ bi tʃɹiɾəd laɪk əsæsənz? ɑnkɑlə dɪd nɑt laɪk ðə kwin, tʃɹu, bʌɾ əɹ fæmli ən tɑlænəz wɝ swɔɹn tə əlidʒəns kəz ə ðɛɹ ɡɹieɪtmɑðɝz, hu hæd bɪn fɝst-sɪstɝz.

"We have something for you," Hehyal said, taking out a leather pouch and handing it to one of the Queen's Guards. The man opened it, inspecting the papers inside. Another insult. Must they be treated like assassins? Oncala did not like the Queen, true, but her family and Talana's were sworn to allegiance because of their greatmothers, who had been first-sisters.

ðə soʊlʒɝ hændəd ðə kwin ðə peɪpɝz. tɑlænə pɝuz ðɛm, feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ kənsɝn ən θɔtfəl.

The soldier handed the Queen the papers. Talana perused them, face growing concerned and thoughtful.

tɑlænə, laɪk moʊst ə ðə ɹulɝz bɪniθ ðə dʒɹæɡənz pis, wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn. ðə ɹeɪvən ɛmpaɪɝz tɛkniks ən skɪl wɪð ʃeɪpɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ. ði il hæɾ əm hɛld əɾ ə steɪlmeɪt, fəɹ naʊ. wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf ðə sintʃæn wʌn? wəd ðeɪ hoʊl tə ðɛɹ oʊðz?

Talana, like most of the rulers beneath the Dragon's Peace, worried about the Seanchan. The Raven Empire's techniques and skill with shaping the One Power were growing. The Aiel had them held at a stalemate, for now. What would happen if the Seanchan won? Would they hold to their oaths?

haʊ mʌtʃ kəd ðə sintʃæn bi tʃɹʌstɪd? hɛjəlz eɪdʒəns hæd spɛn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm oʊvɝ ðə læs dɛkeɪd siɾɪŋ ðət vɛɹi kwɛstʃən əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt kɔɹts ə ðə wɝld. hi wɑz ə waɪz mæn. ivən bɪfɔɹ i hæd bɪkʌm tʃif, hi hæd ɹilaɪz ðət ðɪs wɔɹ kəd nɑt bi wʌn baɪ ði il əloʊn. ðeɪ niɾəd ðiz sɑft wɛtləndɝz.

How much could the Seanchan be trusted? Hehyal's agents had spent a great deal of time over the last decade seeding that very question among the great courts of the world. He was a wise man. Even before he had become chief, he had realized that this war could not be won by the Aiel alone. They needed these soft wetlanders.

ən ðət wɑz ðə faɪnəl ɹizən ɑnkɑlə heɪɾəd ðɛm.

And that was the final reason Oncala hated them.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðiz?" tɑlænə æskt.

"Where did you get these?" Talana asked.

"fɹʌm ðə sintʃæn pæləs," hɛjəl sɛd. "ðeɪ ʃəd nɑɾ əv stʃɹʌk ət ɹɪɾiən. baɪ ɑnɝ, ðəɾ əlaʊɾ əs tə ɹɪsɪpɹəkeɪt - ðoʊ əɹ ətæk wɑz dʌn kwaɪətli tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ðiz. aɪ hæd lɔŋ səspɛktəd wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ loʊkeɪɾəd, ən oʊnli maɪ ɑnɝ ɪn nɑt bɹitʃɪŋ ðə sintʃæn seɪkɹəd pæləs hɛl mi bæk."

"From the Seanchan palace," Hehyal said. "They should not have struck at Rhuidean. By honor, that allowed us to reciprocate - though our attack was done quietly to recover these. I had long suspected where they were located, and only my honor in not breaching the Seanchan sacred palace held me back."

tɑlænəz feɪs ɡɹu hɑɹd. "jɔɹ sɝɾən ðiz ɑɹ əθɛntɪk?"

Talana's face grew hard. "You're certain these are authentic?"

"ju kwɛstʃən mi?" hɛjəl æskt.

"You question me?" Hehyal asked.

kwin tɑlænə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, lʊkɪŋ tʃɹʌbəld. ʃi nu ðət ði il dɪd nɑt laɪ.

Queen Talana shook her head, looking troubled. She knew that the Aiel did not lie.

"wi hæv bɪn peɪʃənt wɪð ju," hɛjəl sɛd. "wi hæv kʌm tə jə ən ɪkspleɪnd wʌt wɪl hæpən ɪf wi kænɑt hoʊld ɔf ðə sintʃæn."

"We have been patient with you," Hehyal said. "We have come to you and explained what will happen if we cannot hold off the Seanchan."

"ðə dʒɹæɡənz pis - "

"The Dragon's Peace - "

"wʌt kɛɹ də ðeɪv fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən?" hɛjəl æskt. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪnveɪɾɝz u fɔɹst ɪm tə baʊ tə ðɛɹ ɛmpɹɛs. ʃiz kənsɪɾɝd əbʌv hɪm. ðəl nɑt kip pɹɑməsəz ðeɪ meɪd tə ən ɪnfɪɹiɝ."

"What care do they have for the Dragon?" Hehyal asked. "They are invaders who forced him to bow to their Empress. She is considered above him. They will not keep promises they made to an inferior."

kwin tɑlænə lʊk daʊn əɡɛn. ðə dɑkjəməns wɝ sintʃæn plænz fəɹ ətækɪŋ ændɝ, əlɔŋ wɪð ə dɪteɪl plɑt fəɹ ði əsæsəneɪʃən ə ðə kwin. ʌndɝniθ ðət wɝ sɪməlɝ plænz fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹulɝz ə tɛɹ, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən ɪljən.

Queen Talana looked down again. The documents were Seanchan plans for attacking Andor, along with a detailed plot for the assassination of the Queen. Underneath that were similar plans for dealing with the rulers of Tear, the Two Rivers, and Illian.

"aɪ mʌst əv taɪm tə kənsʌlt wɪð maɪ ædvaɪzɝz," tɑlænə sɛd.

"I must have time to consult with my advisors," Talana said.

wɪv hɝ, ɑnkɑlə θɔt, smaɪlɪŋ. ɑnkɑlə ɔlɹɛɾi nu wʌt ðə kwinz ænsɝ wəd bi.

We have her, Oncala thought, smiling. Oncala already knew what the Queen's answer would be.

ðə tʃɹɪk hæd bɪn tə ɡɛɾ əɹ tə kənsɪɾɝ ækʃən.

The trick had been to get her to consider action.

hɛjəl nɑɾəd, ən ðə tu ʌv əm wɪθdʒɹu. ɑnkɑlə hæd tə kip hɝsɛlf fɹəm jɛlɪŋ ɪn vɪktɝi.

Hehyal nodded, and the two of them withdrew. Oncala had to keep herself from yelling in victory.

ɪf ændɝ ɛntɝd ðə wɔɹ, ði ʌðɝ neɪʃənz wəɾ əz wɛl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðoʊz ɪn ðə pækt ə ðə ɡɹɪfɪn ən ðoʊz ɪn ðə kɔɹɾ ə ðə sʌn. ðeɪ lʊk tə ði ændɔɝən kwin mʌtʃ əz ði ʌðɝ il klænz lʊk tə ɑnkɑlə. ðə blʌɾ ə ɹænd ælθɹ hɛl mʌtʃ weɪt.

If Andor entered the war, the other nations would as well, particularly those in the Pact of the Griffin and those in the Court of the Sun. They looked to the Andoran Queen much as the other Aiel clans looked to Oncala. The blood of Rand al'Thor held much weight.

"ɪz ðɪs ɹaɪt?" hɛjəl æskt əz ðeɪ wɔkt, ðɛɹ spɪɹz sɝaʊndɪŋ əm tə kip əweɪ pɹaɪɪŋ ɪɹz.

"Is this right?" Hehyal asked as they walked, their spears surrounding them to keep away prying ears.

ɑnkɑlə stɑɹɾəd. "ɪt wɑz jəɹ plæn."

Oncala started. "It was your plan."

hi nɑɾəd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

He nodded, frowning.

nʌθɪŋ i hæd sɛd tə ðə kwin hæd bɪn əntʃɹu. ðɛɹ ɑnɝ wɑz ənsɔɪld. haʊɛvɝ, hɛjəl hæd lɛft aʊt wʌn ə ðə ʃits ðeɪd dɪskʌvɝd. ðət wʌn hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ðət ði ʌðɝ ʃits wɝ kəntɪnʒənsi plænz.

Nothing he had said to the Queen had been untrue. Their honor was unsoiled. However, Hehyal had left out one of the sheets they'd discovered. That one had explained that the other sheets were contingency plans.

ðə dɪskɹɪpʃənz ʌv ændɝz mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹsɪz, sədʒɛstʃənz ɑn haʊ tə juz ɡeɪtweɪz ən dʒɹæɡənz tə ətæk keɪɛmlɪn, ðə vɛɹi plɑt tə əsæsəneɪt kwin tɑlænə - ðiz hæd bɪn dʒɹɔn ʌp oʊnli ɪn keɪs ændɝ ɛntɝd ðə wɔɹ. ðeɪ wɝ mɛn əz ə pɹiɛmptɪv stʌɾi ɑn ə pətɛnʃəl ɛnəmi, nɑɾ ən æktʃəwəl plæn tə ətæk.

The descriptions of Andor's military forces, suggestions on how to use gateways and dragons to attack Caemlyn, the very plot to assassinate Queen Talana - these had been drawn up only in case Andor entered the war. They were meant as a preemptive study on a potential enemy, not an actual plan to attack.

ɪt wɑz vɝtʃuəli ðə seɪm θɪŋ. ðə sintʃæn wɝ sneɪks. ðeɪ wəd siz ændɝ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ən baɪ ðən ði il maɪt bi əneɪbəl tə hɛlp. ɪf ðɪs wɔɹ wɛn bædli, hɝ pipəl wəd ɡoʊ tə ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ən liv ðə fulɪʃ wɛtləndɝz tə bi kɑŋkɝd. ðə sintʃæn wəd faɪn ɪɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə faɪt ði il ɪn ðɛɹ hoʊmlænd.

It was virtually the same thing. The Seanchan were snakes. They would seize Andor eventually, and by then the Aiel might be unable to help. If this war went badly, her people would go to the Three-fold Land and leave the foolish wetlanders to be conquered. The Seanchan would find it impossible to fight the Aiel in their homeland.

mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ fəɹ kwin tɑlænə tə ɛntɝ ðə wɔɹ naʊ. fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɡʊd, ɪt wɑz bɛst ʃi nɛvɝ sɔ ðəɾ ʌðɝ ʃit.

Much better for Queen Talana to enter the war now. For her own good, it was best she never saw that other sheet.

"ɪɾ ɪz dʌn," hɛjəl sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɹum fəɹ kwɛstʃən naʊ."

"It is done," Hehyal said. "There is no room for question now."

ɑnkɑlə nɑɾəd. ðə sintʃæn wəd fɔl, ən ði il wəd teɪk ðɛɹ ɹaɪtfəl pleɪs. ðə blʌɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ɪn əɹ veɪnz. ʃi dɪzɝv tə ɹul.

Oncala nodded. The Seanchan would fall, and the Aiel would take their rightful place. The blood of the Dragon Reborn was in her veins. She deserved to rule.

ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðə ɹeɪvən ɛmpaɪɝ ðət ɹoʊz ət ði ɛn ə ðɪs ɔl, bʌt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɛmpaɪɝ.

It would not be the Raven Empire that rose at the end of this all, but the Dragon Empire.

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə ɡoʊ ɑn," eɪvinhə sɛd tə ði ɛmpti fɔɹəst ʌv ɡlæs.

"I don't want to go on," Aviendha said to the empty forest of glass.

ðə bɹiz hæd fɔlən stɪl. hɝ kɑmɛnt wɑz mɛt wɪð saɪləns. hɝ tɪɹz hæd mɑɹk ðə dʌs baɪ hɝ fit, laɪk fɔlən dʒɹɑps ə ɹeɪn.

The breeze had fallen still. Her comment was met with silence. Her tears had marked the dust by her feet, like fallen drops of rain.

"ðæt . . . kɹitʃɝ hæd noʊ ɑnɝ," ʃi sɛd. "ʃi hæz ɹuən ʌs."

"That . . . creature had no honor," she said. "She has ruined us."

ðə wɝs pɑɹt wɑz, ðə wʊmən - ɑnkɑlə - hæd θɔɾ ə hɝ mɔθ-ɝz mʌðɝ. hɝ ɡɹieɪtmɑðɝ.

The worst part was, the woman - Oncala - had thought of her moth-er's mother. Her greatmother.

ɪnsaɪɾ oʊkæləz hɛd, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə feɪs ətætʃt tə ðət taɪɾəl. eɪvinhə hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt.

Inside Ocala's head, there had been a face attached to that title. Aviendha had recognized it.

əz əɹ oʊn.

As her own.

kɹɪŋɪŋ, kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz, ʃi stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹeɪɾiənt kɑləmz.

Cringing, closing her eyes, she stepped forward into the very center of the radiant columns.

ʃi wɑz pædʒɹə, dɔɾɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, pɹaʊd meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ. ʃi jæŋkt əɹ wɛpən fɹəm ðə nɛk ʌv ə daɪɪŋ sintʃæn, ðən wɑtʃt ðə ɹɛs fli θɹu ðɛɹ ɡeɪtweɪ.

She was Padra, daughter of the Dragon Reborn, proud Maiden of the Spear. She yanked her weapon from the neck of a dying Seanchan, then watched the rest flee through their gateway.

laɪt kɝs ðə wʌn u tɔt ðə sintʃæn tʃɹævlɪŋ, pædʒɹə θɔt. ivən ɪf ðɛɹ wivz ɑɹən vɛɹi ɛləɡənt.

Light curse the one who taught the Seanchan Traveling, Padra thought. Even if their weaves aren't very elegant.

ʃi wɑz kənvɪɝ? sɛt ðət noʊ lɪvɪŋ pɝsən ʌndɝstʊd ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ʃi ən əɹ sɪblɪŋz dɪd.

She was convir? ced that no living person understood the One Power as she and her siblings did.

ʃid bɪn eɪbəl tə wiv sɪns ʃid bɪn ə tʃaɪld, ən əɹ bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝ wɝ ðə seɪm. tə ðɛm, ɪt wɑz nætʃɹəl, ən ɔl ʌðɝz u tʃænəl simd ɑkwɝd baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən.

She'd been able to weave since she'd been a child, and her brothers and sister were the same. To them, it was natural, and all others who channeled seemed awkward by comparison.

ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl nɑt tə spik ðət weɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz dɪdn laɪk biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðɛɹ ʃɔɹtkʌmɪŋz. ɪt wɑz tʃɹu nʌnðəlɛs.

She was careful not to speak that way. Aes Sedai and Wise Ones didn't like being reminded of their shortcomings. It was true nonetheless.

pædʒɹə dʒɔɪn əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz. ðeɪ lɛft wʌn ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ dɛɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹæs, ən pædʒɹə mɔɹn fəɹ hɝ. tɑɹə, ʌv ðə tɑɹdæɾ il. ʃi wəd bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. bʌɾ ɑnɝ wɑz ðɛɹz, fəɹ ðeɪ hæd sleɪn eɪt sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz.

Padra joined her spear-sisters. They left one of their number dead on the grass, and Padra mourned for her. Tarra, of the Taardad Aiel. She would be remembered. But honor was theirs, for they had slain eight Seanchan soldiers.

ʃi woʊv ə ɡeɪtweɪ - fəɹ hɝ, ɪt hæpən əz fæst əz ʃi kəd θɪŋk. ʃi hɛl ðə wʌn paʊɝ pɝpɛtʃuəli, ivən waɪl ʃi slɛpt. ʃid nɛvɝ noʊn wʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk nɑt tə hæv ðət kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, sɝdʒɪŋ paʊɝ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd. ʌðɝz sɛd ðeɪ fɪɹd biɪŋ kənsum baɪ ɪt, bʌt haʊ wɑz ðət pɑsəbəl? seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz ə pis ə hɝ, laɪk əɹ ɑɹm əɹ əɹ lɛɡ. haʊ kəd wʌn bi kənsum baɪ wʌnz oʊn flɛʃ, boʊn ən blʌd?

She wove a gateway - for her, it happened as fast as she could think. She held the One Power perpetually, even while she slept. She'd never known what it was like not to have that comforting, surging Power in the back of her mind. Others said they feared being consumed by it, but how was that possible? Saidar was a piece of her, like her arm or her leg. How could one be consumed by one's own flesh, bone and blood?

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ lɛd tə ði il kæmp ɪn ðə læn kɔld ɑɹæd dumən. ðə kæmp wɑzn ə sɪɾi; il dɪdn əv sɪɾiz. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ kæmp, ən ɪt hæd nɑt muvd ɪn ɔlmoʊst ə dɛkeɪd. pædʒɹə stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹæs, ən il ɪn keɪɾɪnsɝ ʃoʊɾ əɹ dɛfɝəns. pædʒɹə ən əɹ sɪblɪŋz, əz tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, hæd bɪkʌm . . . sʌmθɪŋ tə ði il.

The gateway led to the Aiel camp in the land called Arad Doman. The camp wasn't a city; Aiel didn't have cities. But it was a very large camp, and it had not moved in almost a decade. Padra strode across the grass, and Aiel in cadin'sor showed her deference. Padra and her siblings, as children of the Dragon, had become . . . something to the Aiel.

nɑt lɔɹdz - ðət kɑnsɛp meɪɾ əɹ sɪk. bʌt ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ. ðə klæn tʃifs lʊk tə hɝ ən əɹ sɪblɪŋz fəɹ æd-vaɪs, ən ðə waɪz wʌnz tʊk spɛʃəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðɛm. ðeɪ əlaʊɾ əɹ tə tʃænəl, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðɛm. ʃi kəd noʊ sunɝ stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ ðən ʃi kəd stɑp bɹiðɪŋ.

Not lords - that concept made her sick. But she was more than an ordinary algai'd'siswai. The clan chiefs looked to her and her siblings for ad-vice, and the Wise Ones took special interest in them. They allowed her to channel, though she was not one of them. She could no sooner stop channeling than she could stop breathing.

ʃi dɪsmɪst əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz, ðən meɪɾ əɹ weɪ dɝɛkli tə ɹɑnəmz tɛnt. ðə klæn tʃif - sʌn ə ɹəɑɹk - wəd nid tə hɪɹ əɹ ɹipɔɹt. ʃi ɛntɝɾ ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si ðət ɹɑnəm wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. ə ɡɹup ə mɛn sæɾ ɑn ðə ɹʌɡ, klæn tʃifs ɛvɹi wʌn. hɝ sɪblɪŋz wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ əz wɛl.

She dismissed her spear-sisters, then made her way directly to Ronam's tent. The clan chief - son of Rhuarc - would need to hear her report. She entered and was surprised to see that Ronam was not alone. A group of men sat on the rug, clan chiefs every one. Her siblings were sitting there as well.

"ɑ, pædʒɹə," ɹɑnəm sɛd. "ju hæv ɹɪtɝnd."

"Ah, Padra," Ronam said. "You have returned."

"aɪ kən kʌm bæk ənʌðɝ taɪm, ɹɑnəm," ʃi sɛd.

"I can come back another time, Ronam," she said.

"noʊ, jə wɝ wɑntəd fəɹ ðɪs miɾɪŋ. sɪɾ ən ʃɛɹ maɪ ʃeɪd."

"No, you were wanted for this meeting. Sit and share my shade."

pædʒɹə baʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ət ði ɑnɝ i ʃoʊd hɝ. ʃi sæt bɪtwin əlɑɹtʃ ən dʒɑnduən, hɝ bɹʌðɝz. ðoʊ ðə fɔɹ sɪblɪŋz wɝ kwɑdʒɹu-plɛts, ðeɪ lʊk vɛɹi dɪssɪməlɝ. əlɑɹtʃ tʊk mɔɹ æftɝ ðɛɹ wɛtləndɝ saɪd, ən hæd dɑɹk hɛɹ. dʒɑnduən wɑz blɑn ən tɔl. bɪsaɪɾ ɪm mɹɪnə, ðɛɹ sɪstɝ, smɔl ə bɪld wɪð ə ɹaʊn feɪs.

Padra bowed her head at the honor he showed her. She sat between Alarch and Janduin, her brothers. Though the four siblings were quadru-plets, they looked very dissimilar. Alarch took more after their wetlander side, and had dark hair. Janduin was blond and tall. Beside him Marinna, their sister, small of build with a round face.

"aɪ ʃəd ɹipɔɹt," pædʒɹə sɛd tə ɹɑnəm, "ðæt ðə sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl wɑz wɛɹ wi θɔt. wi ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðɛm."

"I should report," Padra said to Ronam, "that the Seanchan patrol was where we thought. We engaged them."

ðəɹ wɝ ənkʌmftəɹbəl mʌmbəlz əbaʊt ðæt.

There were uncomfortable mumbles about that.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡənz pis fəɹ əm tə ɛntɝ ɑɹæd dumən" sɛd tɑvələd, klæn tʃif ə ðə ɡoʊʃin il.

"It is not against the Dragon's Peace for them to enter Arad Doman" said Tavalad, clan chief of the Goshien Aiel.

"nɔɹ ɪz ɪt ɹɔŋ fəɹ əs tə kɪl əm fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ tu kloʊs, klæn tʃif" pædʒɹə ɹɪplaɪd. "ði il ɑɹ nɑt baʊn baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡənz pis. ɪf ðə sintʃæn wɪʃ tə ɹɪsk ɪnspɛktɪŋ əɹ kæmp, ðən ðeɪ nid tə noʊ ðəɾ ɪts ə ɹɪsk."

"Nor is it wrong for us to kill them for getting too close, clan chief" Padra replied. "The Aiel are not bound by the Dragon's Peace. If the Seanchan wish to risk inspecting our camp, then they need to know that it is a risk."

sɛvɹəl ə ði ʌðɝz - mɔɹ ðən ʃi wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd - nɑɾəd ət ðət kɑmɛnt. ʃi ɡlænst ət dʒɑnduən, ən i ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ʃi kʌvɝtli ɹeɪz tu fɪŋɡɝz. tu sintʃæn, dɛd baɪ hɝ spɪɹ. ʃi wʊɾə laɪk tə teɪk əm kæptɪv, bʌt ðə sintʃæn dɪd nɑt dɪzɝv tə bɪkʌm ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ meɪd tɛɹəbəl pɹɪznɝz. bɛɾɝ tə spɛɹ əm ðə ʃeɪm ən lɛɾ əm daɪ.

Several of the others - more than she would have expected - nodded at that comment. She glanced at Janduin, and he raised an eyebrow. She covertly raised two fingers. Two Seanchan, dead by her spear.
