She would have liked to take them captive, but the Seanchan did not deserve to become gai'shain. They also made terrible prisoners. Better to spare them the shame and let them die.

"wi ʃəd spik wʌt wi keɪm tə seɪ," sɛɾ əlɔlvd, tʃif ə ðə tə-mənɛl il. pædʒɹə dɪɾ ə kwɪk kaʊnt. ɔl ɪlɛvən tʃifs wɝ əkaʊntəd fɔɹ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðoʊz u hæd blʌɾ oʊðz əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. ə miɾɪŋ laɪk ðɪs hædn bɪn sin ɪn jɪɹz, nɑt sɪns əɹ fɑðɝ hæd bɪn pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

"We should speak what we came to say," said Alalved, chief of the To-manelle Aiel. Padra did a quick count. All eleven chiefs were accounted for, including those who had blood oaths against one another. A meeting like this hadn't been seen in years, not since her father had been preparing for the Last Battle.

"ænd wʌd wi kʌm tə seɪ?" æskt wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz.

"And what did we come to say?" asked one of the others.

əlɔlvd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðə spɪɹz ɡɹoʊ ɹɛsləs. ði il ɑɹ nɑt mɛn tə ɡɹoʊ fæɾ ɪn lʌʃ lænz, tɛndɪŋ kɹɑps. wəɹ wɔɹiɝz."

Alalved shook his head. "The spears grow restless. The Aiel are not meant to grow fat in lush lands, tending crops. We are warriors."

"ðə dʒɹæɡən æsk fəɹ pis," tɑvələd sɛd.

"The Dragon asked for peace," Tavalad said.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən æskt ʌðɝz fəɹ pis," əlɔlvd ɹɪplaɪd. "hi ɪkskluɾəd ði il."

"The Dragon asked others for peace," Alalved replied. "He excluded the Aiel."

"ðæɾ ɪz tʃɹu," sɛd dɑɹvɪn, tʃif ə ðə ɹn.

"That is true," said Darvin, chief of the Reyn.

"du wi ɹɪtɝn tə ɹeɪɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ æftɝ ɔl ə ðiz jɪɹz ə hoʊldɪŋ əɹ blʌd fjudz ɪn əbeɪəns?" ɹɑnəm æsk sɔfli. hi wɑz ən ɛksələn klæn tʃif, mʌtʃ əz ɹəɑɹk hæd bɪn. waɪz, jɛt nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə bæɾəl.

"Do we return to raiding one another after all of these years of holding our blood feuds in abeyance?" Ronam asked softly. He was an excellent clan chief, much as Rhuarc had been. Wise, yet not afraid of battle.

"wʌt wəd bi ðə pɔɪnt?" æskt ʃɛdʒɹən, tʃif ə ðə dɛɹn il. ʌðɝz nɑɾəd. bʌt ðət ɹeɪzd ə lɑɹdʒɝ pɹɑbləm, wʌn əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔfən spoʊkən ʌv. wʌt wɑz ɪt tə bi il, naʊ ðət ðɛɹ duɾi tə ðə pæs hæd bɪn fʊlfɪld, ðɛɹ toʊ əz ə pipəl klɛnzd?

"What would be the point?" asked Shedren, chief of the Daryne Aiel. Others nodded. But that raised a larger problem, one her mother had often spoken of. What was it to be Aiel, now that their duty to the past had been fulfilled, their toh as a people cleansed?

"haʊ lɔŋ kən wi weɪt," əlɔlv sɛd, "noʊɪŋ ðət ðeɪv il wɪmən kæptɪv wɪð ðoʊz bɹeɪslɪts ə ðɛɹz? ɪts bɪn jɪɹz, ən ðeɪ stɪl kəntɪnju tə ɹəfjuz ɔl ɔfɝz ə peɪmən ən bɑɹɾɝ!

"How long can we wait," Alalved said, "knowing that they have Aiel women captive with those bracelets of theirs? It has been years, and they still continue to refuse all offers of payment and barter!

ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn əɹ səvɪləɾi wɪð ɹudnəs ən ɪnsʌls."

They return our civility with rudeness and insults."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt mɛn tə bɛɡ," sɛɾ eɪdʒ bɹəən. "ði il wɪl sun bɪkʌm mɪlk-fɛd wɛtləndɝz."

"We are not meant to beg," said aged Bruan. "The Aiel will soon become milk-fed wetlanders."

ɔl nɑɾəd əɾ ɪz wɝdz. waɪz bɹəən hæd lɪv θɹu ðə læs bæɾəl.

All nodded at his words. Wise Bruan had lived through the Last Battle.

"ɪf oʊnli ðə sintʃæn ɛmpɹɛs . . ." ɹɑnəm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən ʃi nu wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ.

"If only the Seanchan Empress . . ." Ronam shook his head, and she knew what he was thinking.

ði oʊld ɛmpɹɛs, ðə wʌn u hæd ɹul dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz ə ðə læs bæɾəl, hæd bɪn kənsɪɾɝd ə wʊmən ʌv ɑnɝ baɪ ɹɑnəmz fɑðɝ. ən ʌndɝstændɪŋ hæd nɪɹli bɪn ɹitʃt wɪð hɝ, soʊ ɪt wɑz sɛd. bʌt mɛni jɪɹz hæd pæst sɪns əɹ ɹul.

The old empress, the one who had ruled during the days of the Last Battle, had been considered a woman of honor by Ronam's father. An understanding had nearly been reached with her, so it was said. But many years had passed since her rule.

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs," ɹɑnəm kəntɪnjud, "ðə spɪɹz klæʃ; əɹ pipəl faɪt wən ðeɪ mit. ɪts əɹ neɪtʃɝ. ɪf ðə sintʃæn woʊn lɪsən tə ɹizən, ðən wʌt kɑz də wɪv tə liv əm bi?"

"Regardless," Ronam continued, "the spears clash; our people fight when they meet. It is our nature. If the Seanchan won't listen to reason, then what cause do we have to leave them be?"

"ðɪs pis ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz wɪl nɑt læs lɔŋ, ɛniweɪ," əlɔlv sɛd. "skɝmɪʃɪz bɪtwin ðə neɪʃənz ɑɹ kɑmən, ðoʊ nʌn spik ə ðɛm. ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɹikwaɪɝd pɹɑməsəz ə ðə mɑnɑɹks, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɛnfɔɹsmənt. mɛni wɛtləndɝz kænɑt bi hɛld ət ðɛɹ wɝd, ən aɪ wɝi ðət ðə sintʃæn wɪl dɪvaʊɝ əm waɪl ðeɪ skwɑbəl."

"This peace of the Dragon's will not last long, anyway," Alalved said. "Skirmishes between the nations are common, though none speak of them. The Car'a'carn required promises of the monarchs, but there is no enforcement. Many wetlanders cannot be held at their word, and I worry that the Seanchan will devour them while they squabble."

ðəɹ wɝ mɛni nɑdz. oʊnli dɑɹvɪn ən tɑvələd dɪd nɑt sim kənvɪnst.

There were many nods. Only Darvin and Tavalad did not seem convinced.

pædʒɹə hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ. ðeɪ hæd noʊn ðɪs wɑz kʌmɪŋ. ðə skɝmɪʃɪz wɪð ðə sintʃæn, ðə ɹɛsləsnəs ə ðə klænz. ʃi hæd dʒɹimd ə ðɪs deɪ, bʌt fɪɹɾ ɪɾ əz wɛl. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd ɡeɪnd ɡɹeɪt dʒi ɪn bæɾəl. pædʒɹə hæd hæd fju tʃænsəz tə pɹuv hɝsɛlf.

Padra held her breath. They had known this was coming. The skirmishes with the Seanchan, the restlessness of the clans. She had dreamed of this day, but feared it as well. Her mother had gained great ji in battle. Padra had had few chances to prove herself.

ə wɔɹ wɪð ðə sintʃæn . . . ðə pɹɑspɛkt ɪnvɪɡɝeɪɾɪd hɝ. bʌɾ ɪt wəɾ ɔlsoʊ min mʌtʃ dɛθ.

A war with the Seanchan . . . the prospect invigorated her. But it would also mean much death.

I say that we must reclaim our own who are held by the Seanchan," said Marinna. She was training to become a Wise One.

It is what we know how to do."

eɪvinhə blɪŋkt. ðə skaɪ wɑz dɑɹk.

Aviendha blinked. The sky was dark.

She was exhausted. Her mind was drained, her heart opened - as if bleeding out strength with every beat. She sat down in the midst of the dimming columns. Her . . . children. She remembered their faces from her first visit to Rhuidean. She had not seen this. Not that she remembered, at least.

Her tears were dry. How did one react to seeing the utter destruction - no, the utter decay - of one's people? Each step had seemed logical to the people who took it. But each had taken the Aiel toward their end.

ʃəɾ ɛniwʌn əv tə si sətʃ tɛɹəbəl vɪʒənz? ʃi wɪʃt ʃid nɛvɝ stɛp bæk ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst ə pɪlɝz. wɑz ʃi tə bleɪm fəɹ wʌt wɑz tə hæpən? ɪt wɑz əɹ laɪn ðət wəd dum əɹ pipəl.

Should anyone have to see such terrible visions? She wished she'd never stepped back into the forest of pillars. Was she to blame for what was to happen? It was her line that would doom her people.

ðɪs wɑz nɑt laɪk ði ɪvɛns ʃi hæd sin wən pæsɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹɪŋz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ fɝs vɪzət tə ɹɪɾiən. ðoʊz hæd bɪn pɑsəbɪləɾiz. ðɪs deɪz vɪʒənz simd mɔɹ ɹil. ʃi fɛlt ɔlmoʊst sɝɾən ðət wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɪɹiənst wɑz nɑt sɪmpli wʌn ə mɛni pɑsəbɪləɾiz. wʌt ʃi hæd sin wəɾ əkɝ. stɛp baɪ stɛp, ɑnɝ dʒɹeɪn fɹəm əɹ pipəl. stɛp baɪ stɛp, ði il tɝn fɹəm pɹaʊd tə ɹɛtʃɪd.

This was not like the events she had seen when passing into the rings during her first visit to Rhuidean. Those had been possibilities. This day's visions seemed more real. She felt almost certain that what she had experienced was not simply one of many possibilities. What she had seen would occur. Step by step, honor drained from her people. Step by step, the Aiel turned from proud to wretched.

ðəɹ hæd tə bi mɔɹ. æŋɡɹi, ʃi stʊɾ ʌp ən tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp. nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. ʃi wɔkt ɔl ðə weɪ tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə pɪlɝz, ðən tɝnd, fjʊɹiəs.

There had to be more. Angry, she stood up and took another step. Nothing happened. She walked all the way to the edge of the pillars, then turned, furious.

"ʃoʊ mi mɔɹ," ʃi dɪmændəd. "ʃoʊ mi wʌɾ aɪ dɪd tə kɑz ðɪs! ɪt lɪs maɪ lɪniədʒ ðət bɹɔɾ əs ɹuən! wʌɾ ɪz maɪ pɑɹɾ ɪn ɪt?"

"Show me more," she demanded. "Show me what I did to cause this! It lis my lineage that brought us ruin! What is my part in it?"

ʃi wɔkt ɪndə ðə pɪlɝz əɡɛn.

She walked into the pillars again.

nʌθɪŋ. ðeɪ sim dɛd. ʃi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʌtʃt wʌn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ laɪf. noʊ hʌm, noʊ sɛns ə paʊɝ. ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, skwiz-ɪŋ wʌn mɔɹ tiɹ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ʌv itʃ aɪ. ðə tɪɹz tʃɹeɪl daʊn əɹ feɪs, livɪŋ ə laɪn ə koʊld wɛtnəs ɑn əɹ tʃiks.

Nothing. They seemed dead. She reached out and touched one, but there was no life. No hum, no sense of Power. She closed her eyes, squeez-ing one more tear from the corner of each eye. The tears trailed down her face, leaving a line of cold wetness on her cheeks.

'kæn aɪ tʃeɪnʒ ɪt?" ʃi æskt.

'Can I change it?" she asked.

ɪf aɪ kænt, ʃi θɔt, wɪl ðət stɑp mi fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ?

If I can't, she thought, will that stop me from trying?

ði ænsɝ wɑz sɪmpəl. noʊ. ʃi kəd nɑt lɪv wɪθaʊt duɪŋ sʌm-θɪŋ tə əvɝt ðət feɪt. ʃi hæd kʌm tə ɹɪɾiən sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ. wɛl, ʃi hæd ɹəsivd ɪt. ɪn mɔɹ əbʌndəns ðən ʃi hæd wɑntəd.

The answer was simple. No. She could not live without doing some-thing to avert that fate. She had come to Rhuidean seeking knowledge. Well, she had received it. In more abundance than she had wanted.

ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz ən ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. il tʊk ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. il fɔt. il stʊd fəɹ ɑnɝ. ɪf ʃi wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn wsɪks nu ðə tɛɹɝz ə ðɛɹ fjutʃɝ, ðən ɪt wɑz əɹ duɾi - əz ə waɪz wʌn - tə ækt. ʃi wəd seɪv əɹ pipəl.

She opened her eyes and gritted her teeth. Aiel took responsibility. Aiel fought. Aiel stood for honor. If she was the only one wh6 knew the terrors of their future, then it was her duty - as a Wise One - to act. She would save her people.

ʃi wɔk fɹəm ðə pɪlɝz, ðən bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ɹʌn. ʃi niɾəd tə ɹɪtɝn, tə kənsʌlt wɪð ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz. bʌt fɝst ʃi niɾəd kwaɪət, aʊɾ ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. taɪm tə θɪŋk.

She walked from the pillars, then broke into a run. She needed to return, to consult with the other Wise Ones. But first she needed quiet, out in the Three-fold Land. Time to think.


tʃæptɝ fɪfti


CHAPTER 50

tʃuzɪŋ ɛnəmiz


Choosing Enemies

ɪleɪn sæɾ æŋkʃəsli, hænz ɪn əɹ læp, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə dɪstən bumz. ʃiɾ ɪntɛnʃənəli tʃoʊzən ðə θɹoʊn ɹum, ɹæðɝ ðən ə lɛs fɔɹməl ɑɾiəns tʃeɪmbɝ. tədeɪ, ʃi niɾəd tə bi sin əz ə kwin.

Elayne sat anxiously, hands in her lap, listening to the distant booms. She'd intentionally chosen the throne room, rather than a less formal audience chamber. Today, she needed to be seen as a queen.

ðə θɹoʊn ɹum wɑz ɪmpoʊzɪŋ, wɪð ɪts mədʒɛstɪk pɪlɝz ən lævɪʃ ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən. ɡoʊldən stænd- læmps bɝn ɪn ə lɔŋ dʌbəl ɹoʊ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, bɹeɪkɪŋ oʊnli fəɹ ðə pɪlɝz.

The throne room was imposing, with its majestic pillars and lavish ornamentation. Golden stand- lamps burned in a long double row on either side of the room, breaking only for the pillars.

ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɪn waɪɾ ən ɹɛd stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts ɡlimɪŋ. ðə mɑɹbəl kɑləmz wɝ mætʃt baɪ ðə θɪk kɹɪmzən ɹʌɡ, woʊvən wɪð ðə laɪən ʌv ændɝ ɪn ɡoʊld əɾ ɪts sɛntɝ. ɪt lɛd təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn, wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn. hɝ ɡaʊn wɑz æftɝ ə tʃɹədɪʃənəl fæʃən ɹæðɝ ðən ðoʊz feɪvɝɾ ɪn kɔɹt ɹaɪt naʊ; ðə slivz wɝ waɪd, wɪð ðə kʌfs dɪzaɪn tə dʒɹup daʊn tə ə ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd pɔɪn bɪniθ əɹ hænd.

Guardsmen in white and red stood in front of them, burnished breastplates gleaming. The marble columns were matched by the thick crimson rug, woven with the Lion of Andor in gold at its center. It led toward Elayne, wearing the Rose Crown. Her gown was after a traditional fashion rather than those favored in court right now; the sleeves were wide, with the cuffs designed to droop down to a gold-embroidered point beneath her hand.

ðət pæɾɝn wɑz ɛkoʊd baɪ ðə bɑɾəs, wɪtʃ wɑz haɪ ɪnʌf tə bi mɑɾəst, bʌt loʊ ɪnʌf tə ɹimaɪn ɔl ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ə wʊmən. wʌn stɪl ənmɛɹid. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd mɛɹiɾ ə mæn fɹəm kɛɹhin ɝli ɪn əɹ ɹeɪn. ʌðɝz maɪt wʌndɝ ɪf ɪleɪn wəd də ðə seɪm tə səmɛn əɹ hoʊl ðɛɹ.

That pattern was echoed by the bodice, which was high enough to be modest, but low enough to remind all that Elayne was a woman. One still unmarried. Her mother had married a man from Cairhien early in her reign. Others might wonder if Elayne would do the same to cement her hold there.

ənʌðɝ dɪstən bum saʊndəd. ðə nɔɪz ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz faɪɹɪŋ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ fəmɪljɝ. nɑt kwaɪɾ ə klæp ə θʌndɝ - loʊɝ, mɔɹ ɹɛɡjəlɝ.

Another distant boom sounded. The noise of the dragons firing was growing familiar. Not quite a clap of thunder - lower, more regular.

ɪleɪn hæd bɪn tɔt tə kənsil əɹ nɝvəsnəs. fɝs baɪ hɝ tuɾɝz, ən ðən baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Elayne had been taught to conceal her nervousness. First by her tutors, and then by the Aes Sedai.

wʌtɛvɝ səm pipəl θɔt, ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən kəd kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ tɛmpɝ wən ʃi niɾəd tə. ʃi kɛpt əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ læp ən fɔɹst əɹ tʌŋ tə bi stɪl. ʃoʊɪŋ nɝvəsnəs wəd bi fɑɹ wɝs ðən æŋɡɝ.

Whatever some people thought, Elayne Trakand could control her temper when she needed to. She kept her hands in her lap and forced her tongue to be still. Showing nervousness would be far worse than anger.

daɪɛlɪn sæɾ ɪn ə tʃɛɹ nɪɹ ðə θɹoʊn. ðə steɪtli wʊmən wɔɹ i ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ənbaʊn ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən ʃi wɑz wɝkɪŋ kwaɪətli əɾ ə hup ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. daɪɛlɪn sɛɾ ɪt ɹɪlæks hɝ, pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ðə hænz tə də waɪl ðə maɪnd wɑz bɪzi. ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ətɛndəns.

Dyelin sat in a chair near the throne. The stately woman wore he golden hair unbound around her shoulders, and she was working quietly at a hoop of embroidery. Dyelin said it relaxed her, providing something for the hands to do while the mind was busy. Elayne's mother was not in attendance.

tədeɪ, ʃi maɪt bi tu mʌtʃ ʌv ə dɪstʃɹækʃən.

Today, she might be too much of a distraction.

ɪleɪn kʊdn əfɔɹd hɝsɛlf daɪɛlɪnz seɪm lʌɡʒɝi. ʃi niɾəd tə bi sin liɾɪŋ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, "liɾɪŋ" ɔfən tʊk ðə fɔɹm ə sɪɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ θɹoʊn, aɪz fɔɹwɝd, pɹədʒɛktɪŋ dɪtɝməneɪʃən ən kəntʃɹoʊl waɪl ʃi weɪɾəd. ʃʊɹli ðə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən wɑz dʌn baɪ naʊ?

Elayne couldn't afford herself Dyelin's same luxury. She needed to be seen leading. Unfortunately, "leading" often took the form of sitting on her throne, eyes forward, projecting determination and control while she waited. Surely the demonstration was done by now?

ənʌðɝ bum. pɝhæps nɑt.

Another boom. Perhaps not.

ʃi kəd hɪɹ sɑf tʃæɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum. ðoʊz haɪ sits stɪl ɪn keɪɛmlɪn hæd ɹəsivd ə ɹɔɪəl ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə mit wɪð ðə kwin ɪn ə dɪskʌʃən ə sænəteɪʃən ɹɪkwaɪɹməns fəɹ ðoʊz steɪɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ðət miɾɪŋ wəd hæpən ət ðə stʃɹaɪk ə faɪv, bʌt ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz hæd hɪntəd ðə haɪ sits wɝ tə ɝaɪv tu aʊɝz ɝli.

She could hear soft chat in the sitting chamber to the side of the throne room. Those High Seats still in Caemlyn had received a royal invitation to meet with the Queen in a discussion of sanitation requirements for those staying outside the city. That meeting would happen at the strike of five, but the invitations had hinted the High Seats were to arrive two hours early.

ðə wɝɾɪŋ ə ðə mɛsədʒ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɑbviəs. ɪleɪn wɑz gɑnə də sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tədeɪ, ən ʃi wɑz ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ ðə haɪ sits ɝli soʊ ðət ðeɪ kəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ səm sæŋkʃən ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ kɛpt wɛl səplaɪd wɪð dʒɹɪŋks ən smɔl dɪʃəz ə mits ən fɹuts ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. laɪkli, ðə tʃæt ʃi oʊvɝhɝd wɑz spɛkjəleɪʃən əbaʊt wʌt ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɹɪvil.

The wording of the message should have been obvious. Elayne was going to do something important today, and she was inviting the High Seats early so that they could enjoy some sanctioned eavesdropping. They were kept well supplied with drinks and small dishes of meats and fruits in the sitting room. Likely, the chat she overheard was speculation about what she was going to reveal.

ɪf ðeɪ oʊnli nu. ɪleɪn kɛpt əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ læp. daɪɛlɪn kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ niɾəlwɝk, klɪkɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ tə hɝsɛlf əz pʊld aʊɾ ə ɹɔŋ stɪtʃ.

If they only knew. Elayne kept her hands in her lap. Dyelin continued her needlework, clicking her tongue to herself as pulled out a wrong stitch.

æftɝ ə nɪɹli ɪnsʌfɝəbəl weɪt, ðə dʒɹæɡənz stɑp saʊndɪŋ ən ɪleɪn fɛl bɝdʒɪt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə pæləs. sɛndɪŋ əɹ wɪð ðə ɡɹup wɑz ðə bɛst weɪ tə noʊ wən ɪt wɑz ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. ðə taɪmɪŋ tədeɪ niɾəd tə bi hændəld wɪð æbsəlut kɛɹ. ɪleɪn bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt tə stɪl əɹ nɝvz. ðɛɹ.

After a nearly insufferable wait, the dragons stopped sounding and Elayne felt Birgitte returning to the palace. Sending her with the group was the best way to know when it was returning. The timing today needed to be handled with absolute care. Elayne breathed in and out to still her nerves. There.

bɝdʒɪt wɑz ʃʊɹli ɪn ðə pæləs naʊ.

Birgitte was surely in the palace now.

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd tə kæptən ɡaɪbɑn. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bɹɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹɪznɝz.

Elayne nodded to Captain Guybon. It was time to bring in the prisoners.

ə ɡɹup ʌv ɡɑɹdz ɛntɝɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, liɾɪŋ θɹi ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz. snɪfəlɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz stɪl plʌmp, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi. ði oʊldɝ wʊmən wɑz pɹɪɾi, əɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn, hæd ʃi bɪn wɛɹɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ɹæɡz. hɝ lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn aɪz wɝ waɪd wɪð fɹaɪt. əz ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪleɪn maɪt stɪl ɛksəkjut hɝ.

A group of Guards entered a moment later, leading three individuals. Sniffling Arymilla was still plump, despite her captivity. The older woman was pretty, or might have been, had she been wearing more than rags. Her large brown eyes were wide with fright. As if she thought Elayne might still execute her.

ɛləniə wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. ʃi, laɪk ði ʌðɝz, hæd bɪn stʃɹɪpt əɹ əɹ faɪn dʒɹɛs ən wɔɹ ə tæɾɝd ɡaʊn ɪnstɛd, bʌt ʃi hæd klin əɹ feɪs ən dʒɹɛst əɹ ɡoʊl hɛɹ ɪn ə nit bʌn. ɪleɪn dɪdn stɑɹv əɹ əbjuz əɹ pɹɪznɝz. hɝ ɛnəmiz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ, ðeɪ wɝn tʃɹeɪɾɝz tə ændɝ.

Elenia was far more in control. She, like the others, had been stripped or her fine dress and wore a tattered gown instead, but she had cleaned her face and dressed her gold hair in a neat bun. Elayne didn't starve or abuse her prisoners. Her enemies though they were, they weren't traitors to Andor.

ɛləniə ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪleɪn. ðət vʌlpaɪn feɪs ə hɝz wɑz θɔtfəl, kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ. dɪd ʃi noʊ wɛɹ əɹ hʌzbənz ɑɹmi hæd vænɪʃt tə? ðət feɪs fɛlt laɪk ə hɪɾən naɪf, pɹɛs tə ɪleɪnz bæk. nʌn ə hɝ skaʊts hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə dɪskʌvɝ ɪts loʊkeɪʃən. laɪt! pɹɑbləmz ətɑp pɹɑbləmz.

Elenia regarded Elayne. That vulpine face of hers was thoughtful, calculating. Did she know where her husband's army had vanished to? That face felt like a hidden knife, pressed to Elayne's back. None of her scouts had been able to discover its location. Light! Problems atop problems.

ðə θɝd wʊmən wɑz nɑiən ɑɝɔn, ə slɪm, peɪl wʊmən huz blæk hɛɹ hæd lɔs mʌtʃ ʌv ɪts lʌstɝ dʊɹɪŋ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi. ðɪs wʌn hæd sim bɹoʊkən bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn hæd teɪkən əɹ kæptɪv, ən ʃi kɛp bæk fɹəm ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən.

The third woman was Naean Arawn, a slim, pale woman whose black hair had lost much of its luster during her captivity. This one had seemed broken before Elayne had taken her captive, and she kept back from the other two women.

ðə θɹi wɝ pɹɑɾɪd tə ðə fʊɾ ə ðə θɹoʊnz deɪz, ðən fɔɹs daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ niz. ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, ðə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlz wɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ nɔɪzəli fɹəm ðə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz. ðeɪ wəɾ əsum ðət ðeɪd hæpən əpɑn ɪleɪnz dɪspleɪ baɪ æksəɾənt.

The three were prodded to the foot of the throne's dais, then forced down on their knees. In the hallway, the Cairhienin nobles were returning noisily from the demonstration of the dragons. They would assume that they'd happened upon Elayne's display by accident.

"ðə kɹaʊn æknɑlɪdʒɪz nɑiən ɑɝɔn, ɛləniə sɑɝən ən ɛɹəmɪlə mɑɹn," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə laʊd vɔɪs. ðət stɪl ði aʊtsaɪd kɑnvɝseɪʃənz -  boʊθ ðoʊz ə ði ændɔɝən noʊbəlz ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ən ðə kɛɹhinɪn aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ.

"The Crown acknowledges Naean Arawn, Elenia Sarand and Arymilla Marne," Elayne said in a loud voice. That stilled the outside conversations -  both those of the Andoran nobles in the sitting room and the Cairhienin outside in the hallway.

ʌv ðə θɹi, oʊnli ɛləniə dɛɹd ɡlæns ʌp. ɪleɪn mɛt ðə ɡeɪz wɪð wʌn əz hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn, ən ðə wʊmən blʌʃt bɪfɔɹ lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɡɛn. daɪɛlɪn hæd pʊɾ əweɪ hɝ niɾəlwɝk ən wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ kloʊsli.

Of the three, only Elenia dared glance up. Elayne met the gaze with one as hard as stone, and the woman blushed before looking down again. Dyelin had put away her needlework and was watching closely.

"ðə kɹaʊn əz ɡɪvən mʌtʃ θɔt tə jə θɹi," ɪleɪn pɹənaʊnst. "jɔɹ mɪsɡaɪɾɪd wɔɹ əɡɛns tʃɹəkən əz lɛf jə dɛstətut, ən ɹɪkwɛsts fəɹ ɹænsəm əv bɪn tɝn əweɪ baɪ jəɹ ɛɹz ən siənz. jəɹ oʊn haʊsəz əv əbændən ju."

"The Crown has given much thought to you three," Elayne pronounced. "Your misguided war against Trakand has left you destitute, and requests for ransom have been turned away by your heirs and scions. Your own Houses have abandoned you."

hɝ wɝdz ɹæŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹæn θɹoʊn ɹum. ðə wɪmən bɪfɔɹ əɹ baʊd daʊn fɝðɝ.

Her words rang in the grand throne room. The women before her bowed down further.

"ðɪs livz ðə kɹaʊn wɪð ə kənʌnʒɹəm," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ju vɛks əs wɪð jəɹ tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ɪɡzɪstənsɪz. pɝhæps səm kwinz wʊɾə lɛf jə tə pɹɪzən, bʌɾ aɪ faɪn ðət ɹiks ʌv ɪndɪsɪʒən.

"This leaves the Crown with a conundrum," Elayne said. "You vex us with your troubling existences. Perhaps some queens would have left you to prison, but I find that reeks of indecision.

jə wəd dʒɹeɪn maɪ ɹisɔɹsɪz ən meɪk mɛn wɪspɝ ʌv weɪz tə fɹi ju."

You would drain my resources and make men whisper of ways to free you."

ðə hɔl fɛl saɪlən seɪv fəɹ ðə hʌski bɹiðɪŋ ə ðə pɹɪznɝz.

The hall fell silent save for the husky breathing of the prisoners.

"ðɪs kɹaʊn ɪz nɑt pɹoʊn tə ɪndɛsɪsɪvnəs," ɪleɪn pɹənaʊnst. "ɑn ðɪs deɪ, haʊsəz sɑɝənd, mɑɹn ən ɑɝɔn ɑɹ stʃɹɪpt ə taɪɾəl ən ɪsteɪt, ðɛɹ lænz fɔɹfɪt tə ðə kɹaʊn ɪn ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən fəɹ ðɛɹ kɹaɪmz."

"This Crown is not prone to indecisiveness," Elayne pronounced. "On this day, Houses Sarand, Marne and Arawn are stripped of title and estate, their lands forfeit to the Crown in retribution for their crimes."

ɛləniə ɡæspt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp. ɛɹəmɪlə ɡɹoʊnd, slaʊtʃɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə laɪən-sɛntɝd ɹʌɡ. nɑiən dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑnd. ʃi sim nʌm.

Elenia gasped, looking up. Arymilla groaned, slouching down on the lion-centered rug. Naean did not respond. She seemed numb.

mɝmɝɪŋ ɹoʊz ɪmiɾiətli fɹəm ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ðɪs wɑz wɝs ðən ən ɛksəkjuʃən. wən noʊbəlz wɝ ɛksəkjuɾəd, ðeɪ wɝ ət list ɛksəkjuɾəd wɪð ðɛɹ taɪɾəlz - ɪn ə weɪ, ən ɛksəkjuʃən wɑz ən æknɑlɪdʒmən ʌv ə wɝði foʊ. ðə taɪɾəl ən lænz pæst ɑn tə ði ɛɹ, ən ðə haʊs sɝvaɪvd.

Murmuring rose immediately from the sitting room. This was worse than an execution. When nobles were executed, they were at least executed with their titles - in a way, an execution was an acknowledgment of a worthy foe. The title and lands passed on to the heir, and the House survived.

bʌt ðɪs . . . ðɪs wɑz sʌmθɪŋ fju kwinz wəɾ ɛvɝ ətɛmpt. ɪf ɪleɪn wɝ sin əz sizɪŋ læn ən mʌni fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn, ði ʌðɝ noʊbəl wəd junaɪɾ əɡɛns hɝ. ʃi kəd ɡɛs ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃənz ɪn ði ʌð ɹum. hɝ paʊɝ beɪs wɑz ʃeɪki. hɝ ælaɪz, hu hæd stʊd wɪð əɹ bɪfɝ ðə sidʒ ən feɪs ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ɛksəkjuʃən ðɛmsɛlvz, maɪt vɛɹi wɛl naʊ bɪɡɪn tə kwɛstʃən.

But this . . . this was something few queens would ever attempt. If Elayne were seen as seizing land and money for the throne, the other noble would unite against her. She could guess the conversations in the othe room. Her power base was shaky. Her allies, who had stood with her befor the siege and faced the possibility of execution themselves, might very well now begin to question.

bɛs tə muv ɑn kwɪkli. ɪleɪn dʒɛstʃɝd, ən ðə ɡɑɹdz pʊl ðə θɹi pɹɪznɝz tə ðɛɹ fiɾ ən ðən lɛɾ əm tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum ivən dɪfaɪən ɛləniə sim stʌnd. ɪn ɛsəns, ðɪs pɹɑkləmeɪʃən wɑz ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən ə dɛθ. əz sun əz pɑsəbəl, ðeɪ wəd kəmɪt suəsaɪd ɹæðɝ ðən feɪs ðɛɹ haʊsəz.

Best to move on quickly. Elayne gestured, and the Guards pulled the three prisoners to their feet and then led them to the side of the room Even defiant Elenia seemed stunned. In essence, this proclamation was a proclamation of death. As soon as possible, they would commit suicide rather than face their Houses.

bɝdʒɪt nu hɝ kju. ʃi ɛntɝd, liɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹup ə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlz. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪnvaɪɾəd tə ə dɪspleɪ ʌv ændɝz nu wɛpən fəɹ "dɪfɛndɪŋ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ," ən wɝ ə mɪks bænd. ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn ðə ɡɹup wɑz pɹɑbli iðɝ bɝtoʊm seɪɡən əɹ lɔɹstʃɹəm ɛɛsnən.

Birgitte knew her cue. She entered, leading the group of Cairhienin nobles. They had been invited to a display of Andor's new weapon for "defending against the Shadow," and were a mixed band. The most important in the group was probably either Bertome Saighan or Lorstrum Aesnan.

bɝtoʊm wɑz ə ʃɔɹt mæn wɪð ə kaɪndə hænsəmnəs, ðoʊ ɪleɪn wɑz nɑt fɑn ə ðə weɪ ðə kɛɹhinɪn ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd ðɛɹ fɔɹhɛdz. hi wɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ naɪf əɾ ɪz bɛlt - sɔɹdz hæd bɪn fɔɹbɪɾən ɪn ðə kwinz pɹɛzəns - ən sim dɪstɝbd baɪ ɪleɪnz tʃɹitmən ə ðə pɹɪznɝz. əz wɛl i ʃəɾ əv bɪn. hɪz kʌzən, koʊləveɪɪɹ, hæd ɹəsivd ə sɪməlɝ pʌnɪʃmən fɹəm ɹænd, ðoʊ ðət hæd nɑɾ əfɛktəɾ əɹ ɪntaɪɝ haʊs. ʃid hæŋ hɝsɛlf ɹæðɝ ðən feɪs ðə ʃeɪm.

Bertome was a short man with a kind of handsomeness, though Elayne was not fond of the way the Cairhienin shaved and powdered their foreheads. He wore a large knife at his belt - swords had been forbidden in the Queen's presence - and seemed disturbed by Elayne's treatment of the prisoners. As well he should have been. His cousin, Colavaere, had received a similar punishment from Rand, though that had not affected her entire House. She'd hanged herself rather than face the shame.

hɝ dɛθ hæɾ ɛləveɪɾɪd bɝtoʊm, ən waɪl hid bɪn vɛɹi kɛɹfəl nɑt tə meɪk pʌblɪk weɪvz əɡɛnst ɹændz ɹul, ɪleɪnz sɔɹsəz pɪkt ɪm aʊɾ əz wʌn ə ðə meɪdʒɝ pɹaɪvət kɹɪɾɪks ə ɹænd ɪn kɛɹhin.

Her death had elevated Bertome, and while he'd been very careful not to make public waves against Rand's rule, Elayne's sources picked him out as one of the major private critics of Rand in Cairhien.

lɔɹstʃɹəm ɛɛsnən wɑz ə kwaɪət, θɪn mæn u wɔkt wɪð ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, ən tɛndəd tə lʊk daʊn ɪz noʊz. laɪk ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə ɡɹup, hi wɔɹ dɑɹk kloʊðɪŋ æftɝ ðə kɛɹhinɪn fæʃən, hɪz koʊt stʃɹaɪpt wɪð ðə kʌlɝz ə hɪz haʊs. hi hæd ɹɪzən tə pɹɑmənəns fɑloʊɪŋ ɹændz dɪsəpɪɹəns fɹəm kɛɹhin. dɛspɹɪt taɪmz meɪd fəɹ kwɪk ədvænsəz, ən ðɪs mæn hæd nɑt muvd əɡɛnst ɹænd tu kwɪkli, jɛɾ ɔlsoʊ hædn əlaɪd wɪð hɪm. ðət mɪɾəl ɡɹaʊnd ɡeɪv ɪm paʊɝ, ən səm wɪspɝd ðəɾ i wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ sizɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn.

Lorstrum Aesnan was a quiet, thin man who walked with his hands behind his back, and tended to look down his nose. Like the others in the group, he wore dark clothing after the Cairhienin fashion, his coat striped with the colors of his House. He had risen to prominence following Rand's disappearance from Cairhien. Desperate times made for quick advances, and this man had not moved against Rand too quickly, yet also hadn't allied with him. That middle ground gave him power, and some whispered that he was considering seizing the throne.

ʌðɝ ðən ðoʊz tu, ðə kɛɹhinɪn hɪɹ wɝ ə smæɾɝɪŋ ʌv ʌðɝ noʊbɪləɾi. eɪlɪl ɹieɪɾən wɑz nɑt ðə hɛɾ ə hɝ haʊs, bʌt sɪns ðə dɪsəpɪɹəns ə hɝ bɹʌðɝ - ə dɪsəpɪɹəns ðət wɑz lʊkɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ laɪk dɛθ - ʃi hæɾ əsum paʊɝ. ɹieɪɾən wɑz ə paʊɝfəl haʊs. ðə slɪm, mɪɾəl- eɪdʒd wʊmən wɑz tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, ən wɔɹ ə dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛs slæʃt wɪð kʌlɝz, hɝ dʒɹɛs ʃeɪp baɪ hups θɹu ðə skɝts. hɝ fæmli hæd hɛl ðə sʌn θɹoʊn ɹisənli, ɪf oʊnli fəɹ ə ɹɛləɾɪvli ʃɔɹt taɪm, ən ʃi wɑz noʊn tə bi ə voʊkəl səpɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɪleɪn.

Other than those two, the Cairhienin here were a smattering of other nobility. Ailil Riatin was not the head of her House, but since the disappearance of her brother - a disappearance that was looking more and more like death - she had assumed power. Riatin was a powerful House. The slim, middle- aged woman was tall for a Cairhienin, and wore a dark blue dress slashed with colors, her dress shaped by hoops through the skirts. Her family had held the Sun Throne recently, if only for a relatively short time, and she was known to be a vocal supporter of Elayne.

lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi əsiɛlɪn, lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi tʃuliəndɝd, lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi hæmɝɑʃəl, ən lɔɹd mævəbwən hæd ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn ðoʊz ə mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəns. ɔl wɝ ə mɪɾəlɪŋ paʊɝ, ən ɔl - fəɹ wʌn ɹizən əɹ ənʌðɝ -  wɝ laɪkli ɹoʊdblɑks tə ɪleɪn. ðeɪ wɝ ə klʌstɝ ə kɛɹfəli dʌn hɛɹ ən paʊɾɝd fɔɹhɛdz, waɪd dʒɹɛsəz ɑn ðə wɪmən, koʊts ən tʃɹaʊzɝz ɑn ðə mɛn, leɪs ət ðə kʌfs.

Lord and Lady Osiellin, Lord and Lady Chuliandred, Lord and Lady Hamarashle, and Lord Mavabwin had gathered behind those of more importance. All were of middling power, and all - for one reason or another -  were likely roadblocks to Elayne. They were a cluster of carefully done hair and powdered foreheads, wide dresses on the women, coats and trousers on the men, lace at the cuffs.

"maɪ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz," ɪleɪn sɛd, neɪmɪŋ itʃ haʊs ɪn tɝn. "ju hæv ɛndʒɔɪɾ ændɝz dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən?"

"My Lords and Ladies," Elayne said, naming each House in turn. "You have enjoyed Andor's demonstration?"

"ɪndid wi hæv, jəɹ mædʒəsti," læŋki lɔɹstʃɹəm sɛd, boʊɪŋ ɪz hɛd ɡɹeɪʃəsli. "ðoʊz wɛpənz ɑɹ kwaɪt . . . ɪntʃɹiɡɪŋ."

"Indeed we have, Your Majesty," lanky Lorstrum said, bowing his head graciously. "Those weapons are quite . . . intriguing."

hi wɑz ɑbviəsli dɪɡɪŋ fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ɪleɪn blɛst əɹ tuɾɝz fəɹ ðɛɹ ɪnsɪstəns ðət ʃi ʌndɝstæn ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz. "wi ɔl noʊ ðət ðə læs bæɾəl kwɪkli əpɹoʊtʃɪz," ɪleɪn sɛd.

He was obviously digging for information. Elayne blessed her tutors for their insistence that she understand the Game of Houses. "We all know that the Last Battle quickly approaches," Elayne said.

"aɪ θɔt ðət kɛɹhin ʃəd bɛs bi əpɹaɪzd ə ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv ɪts ɡɹeɪɾəst ən kloʊsəst ælaɪ. ðəɹ wɪl bi taɪmz ɪn ðə nɪɹ fjutʃɝ wən wɪl nid tə ɹɪlaɪ əpɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ."

"I thought that Cairhien should best be apprised of the strength of its greatest and closest ally. There will be times in the near future when we will need to rely upon one another."

"ɪndid, jəɹ mædʒəsti," lɔɹstʃɹəm sɛd.

"Indeed, Your Majesty," Lorstrum said.

"jɔɹ mædʒəsti," bɝtoʊm sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ðə ʃɔɹt mæn foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz. "aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, kɛɹhin ɪɡzʌls ɪn ændɝz stʃɹɛŋkθ ən stəbɪlɪɾi."

"Your Majesty," Bertome said, stepping forward. The short man folded his arms. "I assure you, Cairhien exults in Andor's strength and stability."

ɪleɪn aɪd hɪm. wɑz i ɔfɝɪŋ əɹ səpɔɹt? noʊ, ɪt simd i wɑz ɔlsoʊ dɪɡɪŋ, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ɪleɪn wəd dɪklɛɹ hɝsɛlf ə kændəɾeɪt fəɹ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. hɝ ɪntɛntʃənz ʃʊɾə bɪn ɑbviəs baɪ naʊ - sɛndɪŋ səm ə ðə bæn tə ðə sɪɾi hæd bɪn ən ɑbviəs muv, nɪɹli tu ɑbviəs fəɹ ðə sʌɾəl kɛɹhinɪn.

Elayne eyed him. Was he offering her support? No, it seemed he was also digging, wondering if Elayne would declare herself a candidate for the Sun Throne. Her intentions should have been obvious by now - sending some of the Band to the city had been an obvious move, nearly too obvious for the subtle Cairhienin.

"wʊd ðət kɛɹhin hæd sɪməlɝ stəbɪlɪɾi," ɪleɪn sɛd kɛɹfəli.

"Would that Cairhien had similar stability," Elayne said carefully.

sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm nɑɾəd, noʊ daʊt hoʊpɪŋ ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɔfɝ wʌn ə ðɛm ðə θɹoʊn. ɪf ʃi θɹu ændɝz səpɔɹt bɪhaɪnd wʌn ə ðiz, ɪt wəd ɡɛɹənti hɪm əɹ əɹ vɪktɝi. ən ɪt wəd ɡɪv əɹ ə sɪmpəθaɪzɝ əz kɪŋ əɹ kwin.

Several of them nodded, no doubt hoping she intended to offer one of them the throne. If she threw Andor's support behind one of these, it would guarantee him or her victory. And it would give her a sympathizer as King or Queen.

ənʌðɝ maɪɾ əv meɪd ðət plɔɪ. nɑt hɝ. ðət θɹoʊn wəd bi hɝz.

Another might have made that ploy. Not her. That throne would be hers.

"ðə teɪkɪŋ ʌv ə θɹoʊn ɪz ə vɛɹi dɛləkət bɪznəs," lɔɹstʃɹəm sɛd. "ɪɾ əz pɹuvən . . . deɪnʒɝəs ɪn ðə pæst. ən soʊ mɛni ɑɹ hɛzɪɾənt."

"The taking of a throne is a very delicate business," Lorstrum said. "It has proven . . . dangerous in the past. And so many are hesitant."

"ɪndid," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ də nɑɾ ɛnvi kɛɹhin ði ənsɝɾənti ðəɾ ɪts noʊn ðiz læs mʌnθs."

"Indeed," Elayne said. "I do not envy Cairhien the uncertainty that it has known these last months."

ən naʊ ðə moʊmənt. ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "feɪst wɪð ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ændɝ, wʌn maɪt θɪŋk ðɪs wəd bi ən ɑbviəs taɪm tə hæv stʃɹɔŋ əlaɪənsəz. ɪn fækt, ðə θɹoʊn ɹisənli əkwaɪɝd sɛvɹəl ɪsteɪts ə noʊ smɔl minz. ɪɾ əkɝz tə mi ðət ðiz ɪsteɪts əv noʊ stuɝdz."

And now the moment. Elayne took a deep breath. "Faced with the strength in Andor, one might think this would be an obvious time to have strong alliances. In fact, the throne recently acquired several estates of no small means. It occurs to me that these estates have no stewards."

ɔl ɡɹu kwaɪət. ðə wɪspɝz ɪn ði ʌðɝ ɹum stɑpt. hæd ðeɪ hɝd kɝɛkli? hæɾ ɪleɪn ɔfɝɾ ɪsteɪts ɪn ændɝ tə fɔɹən noʊbɪləɾi?

All grew quiet. The whispers in the other room stopped. Had they heard correctly? Had Elayne offered estates in Andor to foreign nobility?

ʃi hɪɾ əɹ smaɪl. sloʊli, səm ə ðɛm ɡɑɾ ɪt. lɔɹstʃɹəm ɡeɪv ə slaɪ smaɪl, ən i nɑɾəd tə hɝ ɛvɝ soʊ slaɪtli.

She hid her smile. Slowly, some of them got it. Lorstrum gave a sly smile, and he nodded to her ever so slightly.

"kɛɹhin ən ændɝ əv lɔŋ ʃɛɹd fɛloʊʃɪp," ɪleɪn kəntɪnjud, əz ɪf ði aɪdiə wɝ oʊnli naʊ əkɝɪŋ tə hɝ. "aʊɝ lɔɹdz əv mɛɹid jəɹ leɪɾiz, əɹ leɪɾiz jəɹ lɔɹdz, ən wi ʃɛɹ mɛni kɑmən bɑnz ə blʌɾ ən əfɛkʃən. aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk ðə wɪzdəm ʌv ə fju kɛɹhihɪn lɔɹdz wəd bi ə ɡɹeɪɾ ədɪʃən tə maɪ kɔɹt, ən pɝhæps ɛdʒəkeɪt mi əpɑn maɪ hɛɹəɾədʒ ɑn maɪ fɑðɝz saɪd."

"Cairhien and Andor have long shared fellowship," Elayne continued, as if the idea were only now occurring to her. "Our lords have married your ladies, our ladies your lords, and we share many common bonds of blood and affection. I should think the wisdom of a few Cairhiehin lords would be a great addition to my court, and perhaps educate me upon my heritage on my father's side."

ʃi lɑkt aɪz wɪð lɔɹstʃɹəm. wəɾ i baɪt? hɪz lænz ɪn kɛɹhin wɝ smɔl, ən ɪz ɪnfluəns ɡɹeɪt fəɹ ə taɪm - bʌt ðət kəd tɪp. ði ɪsteɪts ʃid siz fɹəm ðə θɹi pɹɪznɝz wɝ əmʌŋ ðə moʊst ɛnviəbəl ɪn əɹ kʌntʃɹi.

She locked eyes with Lorstrum. Would he bite? His lands in Cairhien were small, and his influence great for a time - but that could tip. The estates she'd seized from the three prisoners were among the most enviable in her country.

hi hæd tə si ɪt. ɪf ʃi tʊk ðə θɹoʊn ə kɛɹhin baɪ fɔɹs, ðə pipəl ən ðə noʊbɪləɾi wəd ɹəbɛl əɡɛns hɝ. ðət wɑz pɑɹʃəli lɔɹstʃɹəmz fɔlt, ɪf əɹ səspɪʃənz wɝ tʃɹu.

He had to see it. If she took the throne of Cairhien by force, the people and the nobility would rebel against her. That was partially Lorstrum's fault, if her suspicions were true.

bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ʃi ɡeɪv lænz wɪðɪn ændɝ tə səm ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbɪləɾi? wʌɾ ɪf ʃi kɹieɪɾəd mʌltəpəl bɑnz bɪtwin ðɛɹ kʌntʃɹiz? wʌɾ ɪf ʃi pɹuv ðət ʃi wəd nɑt stil ðɛɹ taɪɾəlz - bʌt wəɾ ɪnstɛd bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv səm ə ðɛm ɡɹeɪɾɝ hoʊldɪŋz? wəd ðət bi ɪnʌf tə pɹuv ðət ʃi dɪdn ɪntɛn tə stil ðə lænz ə ðə kɛɹhin noʊbɪləɾi ən ɡɪv əm tə hɝ oʊn pipəl? wəd ðəɾ iz ðɛɹ wɝiz?

But what if she gave lands within Andor to some of the Cairhienin nobility? What if she created multiple bonds between their countries? What if she proved that she would not steal their titles - but would instead be willing to give some of them greater holdings? Would that be enough to prove that she didn't intend to steal the lands of the Cairhien nobility and give them to her own people? Would that ease their worries?

lɔɹstʃɹəm mɛɾ əɹ aɪz. "aɪ si ɡɹeɪt pətɛnʃəl fəɹ əlaɪənsəz."

Lorstrum met her eyes. "I see great potential for alliances."

bɝtoʊm wɑz nɑɾɪŋ ɪn əpɹiʃieɪʃən. "aɪ tu, θɪŋk ðɪs kəd bi ɝeɪnʒd." niðɝ wəd ɡɪv ʌp ðɛɹ lænz, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ sɪmpli plæn tə ɡeɪn ɪsteɪts ɪn ændɝ. wɛlθi wʌnz.

Bertome was nodding in appreciation. "I too, think this could be arranged." Neither would give up their lands, of course. They simply planne to gain estates in Andor. Wealthy ones.

ði ʌðɝz ʃɛɹd ɡlænsɪz. leɪɾi əsiɛlɪn ən lɔɹd mævəbwən wɝ ðə fɝs tu tə fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊt.

The others shared glances. Lady Osiellin and Lord Mavabwin were the first two to figure it out.

ðeɪ spoʊk ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɔfɝɪŋ əlaɪənsəz.

They spoke at the same time, offering alliances.

ɪleɪn stɪld əɹ æŋkʃəs hɑɹt, sɪɾɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə θɹoʊn. "aɪ hæv bʌt wʌn mɔɹ ɪsteɪt tə ɡɪv,"

Elayne stilled her anxious heart, sitting back in the throne. "I have but one more estate to give,"

ʃi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv ɪt kəd bi dɪvaɪɾəd.' ʃi wəd ɡɪv səm tə eɪlɪl ɔlsoʊ, tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ ən ɹɪwɔɹɾ əɹ səpɔɹt. naʊ fəɹ ðə sɛkən pɑɹɾ ə ðə plɔɪ. "leɪɾi sɑɝənd," ɪleɪn kɔl təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum.

she said. "But I believe it could be divided.' She would give some to Ailil also, to curry favor and reward her support. Now for the second part of the ploy. "Lady Sarand," Elayne called toward the back of the room.

ɛləniə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɹæɡz.

Elenia stepped forward, wearing her rags.

"ðə kɹaʊn ɪz nɑt wɪθaʊt mɝsi," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ændɝ kænɑt fɝɡɪv jə fəɹ ðə peɪn ən sʌfɝɪŋ jə kɑzd. bʌɾ ʌðɝ kʌntʃɹiz əv noʊ sətʃ mɛmɹiz. tɛl mi, ɪf ðə kɹaʊn wɝ tə pɹəvaɪd jə wɪð ən ɑpɝtunəɾi fəɹ nu lænz, wəd ðəɾ ɑpɝtunəɾi bi teɪkən?"

"The Crown is not without mercy," Elayne said. "Andor cannot forgive you for the pain and suffering you caused. But other countries have no such memories. Tell me, if the Crown were to provide you with an opportunity for new lands, would that opportunity be taken?"

"nu lænz, jəɹ mædʒəsti?" ɛləniə æskt. "ʌv wɪtʃ lænz dʒju spik?"

"New lands, Your Majesty?" Elenia asked. "Of which lands do you speak?"

"ə junəfəkeɪʃən bɪtwin ændɝ ən kɛɹhin wəɾ ɔfɝ mɛni ɑpəɾunətiz," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"A unification between Andor and Cairhien would offer many oppotunities," Elayne said.

"pɝhæps juv hɝɾ ə ðə kɹaʊnz əlaɪəns wɪð ɡildən. pɝhæps juv hɝɾ ə ðə nuli ɹivaɪɾəlaɪzd lænz ɪn ðə wɛst ə ɹɛlm. ðɪs ɪz ə taɪm ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ɑpɝtunəɾi. ɪf aɪ wɝ tə faɪn jə ən jəɹ hʌzbən ə pleɪs tə fɔɹm ə nu siɾ ɪn kɛɹhin, wəd jə teɪk wʌɾ ɪz ɡɪvən?"

"Perhaps you have heard of the Crown's alliance with Ghealdan. Perhaps you have heard of the newly revitalized lands in the west of realm. This is a time of great opportunity. If I were to find you and your husband a place to form a new seat in Cairhien, would you take what is given?"

"aɪ . . . wəd sɝɾənli kənsɪɾɝ ɪt, jəɹ mædʒəsti," ɛləniə sɛd, ʃoʊɪŋ ə ɡlɪmɝ ə hoʊp.

"I . . . would certainly consider it, Your Majesty," Elenia said, showing a glimmer of hope.

ɪleɪn tɝn tə ðə kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹdz. "fɔɹ ɛni ʌv ðɪs tə teɪk ɪfɛkt," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ wəd niɾ əθɔɹəɾi tə spik fəɹ boʊθ ændɝ ən kɛɹhin. haʊ lɔŋ, dʒju səspɛkt, maɪɾ ɪt teɪk fəɹ sətʃ ə sɪtʃueɪʃən tə bi ɝeɪnʒd?"

Elayne turned to the Cairhienin lords. "For any of this to take effect," she said, "I would need authority to speak for both Andor and Cairhien. How long, do you suspect, might it take for such a situation to be arranged?"

"ɹɪtɝn mi tə maɪ hoʊmlæn θɹu wʌn ə ðoʊz stʃɹeɪnʒ pɔɹɾəlz," lɔɹstʃɹəm sɛd, "ænd ɡɪmi wʌn aʊɝ."

"Return me to my homeland through one of those strange portals," Lorstrum said, "and give me one hour."

"aɪ niɾ oʊnli ə hæf ən aʊɝ, jəɹ mædʒəsti," bɝtoʊm pʊɾ ɪn, ɡlænsɪŋ ət lɔɹstʃɹəm.

"I need only a half an hour, Your Majesty," Bertome put in, glancing at Lorstrum.

so many problems that need fixing. And only one of me. Go in my place, Naeff, for now. I need information."

She turned her mind to the task at hand. The Borderlander armies had never explained why they'd defied custom and logic by marching south to find Rand. They were needed desperately. Rand's intervention at Maradon had saved what was left of the city, but if that sort of thing was happening all across the border with the Blight. . . .

"Rand al'Thor," one of the men announced. "We are representatives of the Unity of the Border.

wɪl pɹəvaɪɾ ɛskɔɹt."

We will provide escort."

ɹænd nɑɾəd, ən ðə pɹəsɛʃən stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm wɪð ɡɑɹdz.

"Do not be arrogant here, Rand al'Thor," Cadsuane said, trotting up to ride beside him. "But do not back down. Most Borderlanders will respond to strength when they see it."

soʊ. kædzueɪn kɔld ɹænd baɪ neɪm, ɪnstɛɾ ə neɪmɪŋ ɪm "bɔɪ." ɪt simd ə vɪktɝi, ən ɪt meɪd mɪn smaɪl.

So. Cadsuane called Rand by name, instead of naming him "boy." It seemed a victory, and it made Min smile.

"aɪ wɪl əv ðət ɡeɪtweɪ ɹɛɾi," kædzueɪn kəntɪnjud mɔɹ sɔfli. "bʌɾ ɪɾəl bi vɛɹi smɔl. ðə wɛl wɪl oʊnli ɡɪmi ɪnʌf tə meɪk wʌn wiɾ əv tə kɹɔl θɹu. wi ʃʊdnt niɾ ɪt. ðiz pipəl wɪl faɪt fəɹ ju. ðəl wɑnə faɪt fəɹ ju. oʊnli bʌmbəlɪŋ fulɪʃnəs kəd kip əm fɹəm ɪt."

"I will have that gateway ready," Cadsuane continued more softly. "But it will be very small. The Well will only give me enough to make one we'd have to crawl through. We shouldn't need it. These people will fight for you. They will want to fight for you. Only bumbling foolishness could keep them from it."

"ðɛɹ ɪz mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ðæt, kædzueɪn sədaɪ," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd, hɪz vɔɪs hʌʃt. "sʌmθɪŋ dʒɹoʊv əm saʊθwɝd. ðɪs ɪz ə tʃælənʒ, wʌn aɪm ənsɝɾən haʊ tə mit. bʌt jəɹ ædvaɪs ɪz əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd."

"There is more to it than that, Cadsuane Sedai," Rand replied, his voice hushed. "Something drove them southward. This is a challenge, one I am uncertain how to meet. But your advice is appreciated."

kædzueɪn nɑɾəd. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, mɪn pɪkt aʊɾ ə laɪn ə pipəl weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə fɔɹfɹʌn ə ði ɑɹmi. ðəɹ wɝ θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz bɪhaɪnd, stændɪŋ ɪn ɹoʊz. sɑldəiənz, wɪð ðɛɹ baʊd lɛɡz.

Cadsuane nodded. Eventually, Min picked out a line of people waiting at the forefront of the army. There were thousands of soldiers behind, standing in rows. Saldaeans, with their bowed legs.

ʃaɪnɝənz ɪn tɑpnɑts. ɝæfɛlɪn, itʃ soʊlʒɝ wɪð tu sɔɹdz stʃɹæp tə hɪz bæk. kændɔɹi, wɪð fɔɹk bɪɹdz.

Shienarans in topknots. Arafellin, each soldier with two swords strapped to his back. Kandori, with forked beards.

ðə ɡɹup ət ðə hɛd stʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɪθaʊt maʊns. ðeɪ wɔɹ faɪn kloʊðɪŋ. tu wɪmən ən tu mɛn, ɔl wɪð wʌt wɝ ɑbviəsli ɛɛs sədaɪ ət ðɛɹ saɪdz, səm wɪð ən ətɛndən əɹ tu bɪhaɪnd.

The group at the head stood on the ground, without mounts. They wore fine clothing. Two women and two men, all with what were obviously Aes Sedai at their sides, some with an attendant or two behind.

"ðə wʌn ət ðə fɹʌn ɪz kwin ɛθɛniɛl," kædzueɪn wɪspɝd. "ʃi ɪz ə stɝn wʊmən, bʌt fɛɹ.

"The one at the front is Queen Ethenielle," Cadsuane whispered. "She is a stern woman, but fair.

ʃiz noʊn fəɹ mɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə ðə sʌðɝn neɪʃənz, ən aɪ səspɛk ði ʌðɝz wɪl lɛɾ əɹ teɪk ðə lɛd tədeɪ. ðə hænsəm mæn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɪz peɪɾɝ nækɪmən, kɪŋ ə ɝæfəl."

She is known for meddling in the affairs of the southern nations, and I suspect the others will let her take the lead today. The handsome man beside her is Paitar Nachiman, King of Arafel."

"hænsəm?" mɪn æskt, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə bɔldɪŋ oʊldɝ ɝæfɛlɪn. ".hɪm?"

"Handsome?" Min asked, inspecting the balding older Arafellin. ".Him?"

"ɪt dɪpɛnz ɑn wʌnz pɝspɛktɪv, tʃaɪld," kædzueɪn sɛd wɪθaʊt mɪsɪŋ ə bit. "hi wɑz wʌns noʊn waɪdli fəɹ ɪz feɪs, ən hiz stɪl noʊn fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd. bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɪz kɪŋ isɑɹ toʊdʒiɾə ʌv ʃaɪnɝ."

"It depends on one's perspective, child," Cadsuane said without missing a beat. "He was once known widely for his face, and he is still known for his sword. Beside him is King Easar Togita of Shienar."

"soʊ sæd," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "hu dɪɾ i luz?"

"So sad," Rand said softly. "Who did he lose?"

mɪn fɹaʊnd. isɑɹ dɪdn lʊk pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sæd tə hɝ. sɑləm, pɝhæps.

Min frowned. Easar didn't look particularly sad to her. Solemn, perhaps.

"hiz ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ," kædzueɪn sɛd. "hiz fɔt ðə tʃɹɑləks ɔl ɪz laɪf; aɪd səspɛk hiz lɔs mɛni ə pɝsən dɪɹ tə hɪm. hɪz waɪf dɪd daɪ səm jɪɹz bæk. hiz sɛd tə hæv ðə soʊl ʌv ə poʊət, bʌt hiz ən ɔstɪɹ mæn. ɪf jə kəɾ ɝn ɪz ɹɪspɛkt, ɪt wəd min mʌtʃ."

"He's a Borderlander," Cadsuane said. "He's fought the Trollocs all his life; I'd suspect he's lost many a person dear to him. His wife did die some years back. He's said to have the soul of a poet, but he is an austere man. If you could earn his respect, it would mean much."

"ðə læst wʌn ɪz tɛnoʊbiə, ðɛn," ɹænd sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "stɪl wɪʃ aɪ hæd bæʃɪɹ wɪð ʌs."

"The last one is Tenobia, then," Rand said, rubbing his chin. "Still wish I had Bashere with us."

bæʃɪɹ hæd sɛd ðəɾ ɪz feɪs maɪt fjuəl tɛnoʊbiəz æŋɡɝ, ən ɹænd hæd lɪsən tə ɹizən ɑn ðət kaʊnt.

Bashere had said that his face might fuel Tenobia's anger, and Rand had listened to reason on that count.

"tɛnoʊbiə," kædzueɪn sɛd, "ɪz ə waɪldfaɪɝ. jʌŋ, ɪmpɝɾənənt ən ɹɛkləs. doʊn lɛɾ əɹ dʒɹɔ jə ɪndə ən ɑɹɡjəmənt."

"Tenobia," Cadsuane said, "is a wildfire. Young, impertinent and reckless. Don't let her draw you into an argument."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. "mɪn?"

Rand nodded. "Min?"

"tɛnoʊbiə hæz ə spɪɹ hʌvɝɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd," mɪn sɛd. "blʌɾi, bʌt ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə laɪt.

"Tenobia has a spear hovering over her head," Min said. "Bloody, but shining in the light.

ɛθɛniɛl wɪl sun bi wɛd - aɪ si ðət baɪ waɪt dʌvz. ʃi plænz tə də sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs tədeɪ, soʊ bi kɛɹfəl. ði ʌðɝ tu hæv vɛɹiəs sɔɹdz, ʃilz ən æɹoʊz hʌvɝɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. boʊθ wɪl faɪt sun."

Ethenielle will soon be wed - I see that by white doves. She plans to do something dangerous today, so be careful. The other two have various swords, shields and arrows hovering about them. Both will fight soon."

"ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl?" ɹænd æskt.

"In the Last Battle?" Rand asked.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ʃi ədmɪɾəd. "ɪt kəd bi hɪɹ, tədeɪ."

"I don't know," she admitted. "It could be here, today."

ðɛɹ ɛskɔɹt lɛɾ əm ʌp tə ðə fɔɹ mɑnɑɹks. ɹænd slɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl, pæɾɪŋ teɪdeɪʃɝ ɑn ðə nɛk əz ðə hɔɹs snɔɹɾɪd. mɪn muv tə dɪsmaʊnt, əz dɪd nɛɹɪʃmə, bʌt ɹænd hɛld ʌp ə hæn tə stɑp ðɛm.

Their escort led them up to the four monarchs. Rand slid out of the saddle, patting Tai'daishar on the neck as the horse snorted. Min moved to dismount, as did Narishma, but Rand held up a hand to stop them.

"blæstəd ful," kædzueɪn mʌɾɝd fɹəm bɪsaɪd mɪn, loʊ ɪnʌf ðət noʊbɑdi ɛls kəd hɪɹ. "hi æsks mi tə bi ɹɛɾi tə ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊt, ðən livz ʌs?"

"Blasted fool," Cadsuane muttered from beside Min, low enough that nobody else could hear. "He asks me to be ready to get him out, then leaves us?"

"hi laɪkli mɛn ðət jə ʃəd ɡɛt mi əweɪ," mɪn sɛd sɔfli. "noʊɪŋ hɪm, hiz mɔɹ wɝiɾ əbaʊt mi ðən hɪmsɛlf." ʃi pɔzd. "blæstəd ful."

"He likely meant that you should get me away," Min said softly. "Knowing him, he's more worried about me than himself." She paused. "Blasted fool."

kædzueɪn ʃɑɾ əɹ ə ɡlæns, ðən smaɪl slaɪtli bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ bæk tə wɑtʃ ɹænd.

Cadsuane shot her a glance, then smiled slightly before turning back to watch Rand.

hi stɛpt ʌp tə ðə fɔɹ mɑnɑɹks ən stɑpt, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz tə ðə saɪdz, əz ɪf tə æsk, "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə wɪʃ ə mi?"

He stepped up to the four monarchs and stopped, raising his arms to the sides, as if to ask, "What is it you wish of me?"

ɛθɛniɛl tʊk ðə lɛd, əz kædzueɪn hæd ɡɛst. ʃi wɑz ə plʌmp wʊmən, hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ pʊld əweɪ fɹəm əɹ feɪs ən taɪɾ ət ðə bæk. ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ɹænd, ə mæn wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ən kæɹiɪŋ ə ʃið sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz ɑɹm, hɪl pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd hɝ.

Ethenielle took the lead, as Cadsuane had guessed. She was a plump woman, her dark hair pulled away from her face and tied at the back. She strode up to Rand, a man walking beside her and carrying a sheathed sword in his arm, hilt pointed toward her.

nɪɹbaɪ, ðə meɪɾənz ɹʌsəld. ðeɪ stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd ɹænd. əz juʒəwəl, ðeɪ əsum ðət kəmænz tə steɪ bæk dɪdn ɪnklud ðɛm.

Nearby, the Maidens rustled. They stepped up beside Rand. As usual, they assumed that commands to stay back didn't include them.

ɛθɛniɛl ɹeɪzd ə hæn ən slæpt ɹænd əkɹɔs ðə feɪs.

Ethenielle raised a hand and slapped Rand across the face.

nɛɹɪʃmə kɝst. ðə meɪɾənz ɹeɪz ðɛɹ veɪlz ən dʒɹu spɪɹz. mɪn nʌdʒd əɹ hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd, bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə laɪn ʌv ɡɑɹdz.

Narishma cursed. The Maidens raised their veils and drew spears. Min nudged her horse forward, breaking through the line of guards.

"stɑp!" ɹænd sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hænd. hi tɝnd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə meɪɾənz.

"Stop!" Rand said, raising his hand. He turned, looking at the Maidens.

mɪn stɪld əɹ mɛɹ, pæɾɪŋ əɹ ɑn ðə nɛk. ʃi wɑz skɪɾɪʃ, əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd. ðə meɪɾənz ɹɪlʌktənli bæk daʊn, ðoʊ kædsu-eɪn dɪd teɪk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə muv əɹ hɔɹs ʌp bɪsaɪd mɪnz.

Min stilled her mare, patting her on the neck. She was skittish, as might be expected. The Maidens reluctantly backed down, though Cadsu-ane did take the opportunity to move her horse up beside Min's.

ɹænd tɝn bæk tə ɛθɛniɛl ən ɹʌbd ɪz feɪs. "aɪ hoʊp ðæts səm tʃɹədɪʃənəl kændɔɹi ɡɹiɾɪŋ, jəɹ mædʒəsti."

Rand turned back to Ethenielle and rubbed his face. "I hope that's some traditional Kandori greeting, Your Majesty."

ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ðən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə saɪd, ən kɪŋ isɑɹ ə ʃaɪnɝ stɛpt ʌp tə ɹænd.

She raised an eyebrow, then gestured to the side, and King Easar of Shienar stepped up to Rand.

ðə mæn bækhændəd ɹænd əkɹɔs ðə maʊθ ðə fɔɹs ʌv ɪt kɑzɪŋ ɹænd tə stʌmbəl.

The man backhanded Rand across the mouth the force of it causing Rand to stumble.

ɹænd ɹaɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf, əɡɛn weɪvɪŋ ðə meɪɾənz daʊn. hi mɛɾ isɑɹz aɪz. ə tʃɹɪkəl ə blʌd ɹæn daʊn ɹændz tʃɪn. ðə ʃaɪnɝən stʌɾid ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən nɑɾəd ən stɛp bæk.

Rand righted himself, again waving the Maidens down. He met Easar's eyes. A trickle of blood ran down Rand's chin. The Shienaran studied him for a moment, then nodded and stepped back.

tɛnoʊbiə keɪm nɛkst. ʃi slæpt ɹænd wɪð əɹ lɛf hænd, ə stʃɹɔŋ bloʊ ðət kɹækt ɪn ði ɛɹ.

Tenobia came next. She slapped Rand with her left hand, a strong blow that cracked in the air.

mɪn fɛlt ə flæʃ ə peɪn fɹəm ɹænd. tɛnoʊbiə ʃʊk əɹ hæn æftɝwɝd.

Min felt a flash of pain from Rand. Tenobia shook her hand afterward.

kɪŋ peɪɾɝ keɪm læst. ði eɪdʒɪŋ ɝæfɛlɪn wɪð oʊnli ə fɹɪnʒ ə hɛɹ wɔkt wɪð ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, kəntɛmpləɾɪv. hi stɛpt ʌp tə ɹænd ən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ən dæbd ət ðə blʌɾ ɑn ɹændz tʃik. ðən i bækhændəd ɹænd wɪð ə bloʊ ðət sɛn ɪm tə hɪz niz, ə spɹeɪ ʌv blʌd flaɪɪŋ fɹəm ɪz maʊθ.

King Paitar came last. The aging Arafellin with only a fringe of hair walked with his hands behind his back, contemplative. He stepped up to Rand and reached over and dabbed at the blood on Rand's cheek. Then he backhanded Rand with a blow that sent him to his knees, a spray of blood flying from his mouth.

mɪn kʊdn sɪt baɪ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. "ɹænd!" ʃi sɛd, dʒʌmpɪŋ daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ən ɹʌnɪŋ tə hɪm. ʃi ɹitʃt ɪz saɪd, stɛɾiɪŋ ɪm waɪl ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə mɑnɑɹks. "haʊ dɛɹ ju! hi keɪm tə jə pisfəli."

Min couldn't sit by any longer. "Rand!" she said, jumping down from her saddle and running to him. She reached his side, steadying him while glaring at the monarchs. "How dare you! He came to you peacefully."

"pisfəli?" peɪɾɝ sɛd. "noʊ, jʌŋ wʊmən, hi dɪd nɑt kʌm tə ðɪs wɝld ɪn pis. hiz kənsum ðə lænd wɪð tɛɹɝ, keɪɑs ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən."

"Peacefully?" Paitar said. "No, young woman, he did not come to this world in peace. He has consumed the land with terror, chaos and destruction."

"æz ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛd ðəɾ i wʊd," kædzueɪn sɛd, wɔkɪŋ ʌp əz mɪn hɛlpt ɹænd bæk tə hɪz fit. "ju leɪ bɪfɔɹ ɪm ðə bɝɾənz ʌv ən ɪntaɪɝ eɪdʒ. jə kænɑt haɪɝ ə mæn tə ɹibɪl jəɹ haʊs, ðən ɹipɹoʊtʃ ɪm wən i mʌs nɑk daʊn ə wɔl tə də ðə dʒɑb."

"As the prophecies said that he would," Cadsuane said, walking up as Min helped Rand back to his feet. "You lay before him the burdens of an entire Age. You cannot hire a man to rebuild your house, then reproach him when he must knock down a wall to do the job."

"ðæt pɹəzumz ðət hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," tɛnoʊbiə sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "wi - "

"That presumes that he is the Dragon Reborn," Tenobia said, folding her arms. "We - "

ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz ɹænd stʊd, ðən kɛɹfəli slɪd kælændɝ fɹəm ɪts ʃiθ, ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ bleɪd ɹæspɪŋ.

She cut off as Rand stood, then carefully slid Callandor from its sheath, glittering blade rasping.

hi hɛld ɪt fɔɹθ. "du jə dɪnaɪ ðɪs, kwin tɛnoʊbiə, ʃild ə ðə nɔɹθ ən sɔɹɾ ə ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs kæzɑɾi? wɪl jə lʊk əpɑn ðɪs wɛpən ən kɔl mi ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən?"

He held it forth. "Do you deny this, Queen Tenobia, Shield of the North and Sword of the Blightborder, High Seat of House Kazadi? Will you look upon this weapon and call me a false Dragon?"

ðət kwaɪəɾəd hɝ. tə ðə saɪd, isɑɹ nɑɾəd. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ɹæŋks ə saɪlən tʃɹups wɑtʃt wɪð lænsɪz, paɪks ən ʃilz hɛl haɪ. əz ɪf ɪn səlut. əɹ əz ɪf ɪn pɹɛpɝeɪʃən tə ətæk. mɪn lʊkt ʌp, ən kəd feɪnli meɪk aʊt pipəl laɪnɪŋ ðə wɔlz ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ tə wɑtʃ.

That quieted her. To the side, Easar nodded. Behind them, ranks of silent troops watched with lances, pikes and shields held high. As if in salute. Or as if in preparation to attack. Min looked up, and could faintly make out people lining the walls of Far Madding to watch.

"lɛɾ əs pɹoʊsid," isɑɹ sɛd. "ɛθɛniɛl?"

"Let us proceed," Easar said. "Ethenielle?"

"vɛɹi wɛl," ðə wʊmən sɛd. "aɪ wɪl seɪ ðɪs, ɹænd ælθɹ. ivən ɪf jə də pɹuv tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, juv mʌtʃ tə ænsɝ fɔɹ."

"Very well," the woman said. "I will say this, Rand al'Thor. Even if you do prove to be the Dragon Reborn, you have much to answer for."

"ju meɪ teɪk jəɹ pɹaɪs fɹəm maɪ skɪn, ɛθɛniɛl," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, slaɪɾɪŋ kælændɝ bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ. "bʌɾ oʊnli wʌns ðə dɑɹk wʌn əz hæɾ ɪz deɪ wɪð mi."

"You may take your price from my skin, Ethenielle," Rand said softly, sliding Callandor back into its sheath. "But only once the Dark One has had his day with me."

"ɹæn ælθɹ," peɪɾɝ sɛd. "aɪ hæv ə kwɛstʃən fəɹ ju. haʊ jə ænsɝ wɪl dətɝmən ði aʊtkʌm ə ðɪs deɪ."

"Rand al'Thor," Paitar said. "I have a question for you. How you answer will determine the outcome of this day."

"wʌt kaɪndə kwɛstʃən?" kædzueɪn dɪmændəd.

"What kind of question?" Cadsuane demanded.

"kædzueɪn, pliz," ɹænd sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ɪz hænd. "lɔɹd peɪɾɝ, aɪ si ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ aɪz. jə noʊ ðəɾ aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪz ðɪs kwɛstʃən nɛsəsɛɹi?"

"Cadsuane, please," Rand said, holding up his hand. "Lord Paitar, I see it in your eyes. You know that I am the Dragon Reborn. Is this question necessary?"

"ɪɾ ɪz vaɪɾəl, lɔɹɾ ælθɹ," peɪɾɝ ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪt dʒɹoʊv əs hɪɹ, ðoʊ maɪ ælaɪz dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪt fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz bɪliv jə tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðət meɪd maɪ kwɛs hɪɹ ivən mɔɹ vaɪɾəl."

"It is vital, Lord al'Thor," Paitar replied. "It drove us here, though my allies did not know it from the start. I have always believed you to be the Dragon Reborn. That made my quest here even more vital."

mɪn fɹaʊnd. ði eɪdʒɪŋ soʊlʒɝ ɹitʃt daʊn tə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, əz ɪf ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɔ. ðə meɪɾənz ɡɹu mɔɹ əlɝt. wɪð ə stɑɹt, mɪn ɹilaɪz peɪɾɝ wɑz stɪl stændɪŋ kloʊs tə ɹænd. tu kloʊs.

hi kəɾ əv ðət sɔɹɾ aʊɾ ən swɪŋɪŋ fəɹ ɹændz nɛk ɪn ən aɪɛblɪŋk, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. peɪɾɝ pleɪs hɪmsɛlf ðəɹ tə bi ɹɛɾi tə stʃɹaɪk.

ɛθɛniɛl lʊk tə isɑɹ, ðən tə tɛnoʊbiə, ðən faɪnəli tə peɪɾɝ. hi nɑɾəd, ðən kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, lɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə saɪ ðət saʊndəd ɹɪlivd. hi tʊk ɪz hæn fɹəm ɪz sɔɹd.

wɪl ænsɝ jəɹ kwɛstʃənz."

It made Cadsuane' shoulders itch, being surrounded like this, but the fool boy - he would al-ways be a fool boy, no matter how old he was -  looked perfectly at peace Thirteen Aes Sedai waited outside the tent, which wasn't large enough for them all. Thirteen. That hadn't made al'Thor blink. What man who could channel would sit amid thirteen Aes Sedai and not sweat?

He's changed, Cadsuane told herself. You're just going to have to accept that Not that he didn't need her anymore. Men like him grew overly confident A few little successes, and he'd trip over his own feet and land in some predicament.

But. . . well, she was proud of him. Grudgingly proud. A little.

Tellindal Tirraso, murdered by his hand, the darkness that came the day after the light. You must ask, and you must know your fate. If he cannot answer . . ."

wʌt dʌz i min baɪ ðæt? kædzueɪn θɔt, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

wɪv tə spik əbaʊt ðæt, baɪ ðə weɪ."

They still looked stunned. Cadsuane rose to go speak with the sisters waiting outside; she knew a few of them, and needed to feel out the others She didn't worry about what the Borderlanders would decide. Al'Thor had them. Another army beneath his banner. I didn't think he'd manage this one.

wʌn mɔɹ deɪ ən ɪɾ ɔl bɪɡæn. laɪt, bʌt ʃi hoʊp ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi.

One more day and it all began. Light, but she hoped that they were ready.

Boots

ɪleɪn sɛɾəld hɝsɛlf ɪn ɡlɪmɝz sæɾəl. ðə mɛɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðə pɹaɪzəz ə ðə ɹɔɪəl steɪbəl; ʃi wɑz ə faɪn sɑldəiən stɑk wɪð ə bɹɪljənt waɪt meɪn ən koʊt. ðə sæɾəl ɪtsɛlf wɑz ɹɪtʃ, ðə lɛðɝ tʃɹɪmd wɪð waɪn-ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə sæɾəl jə juzd wən pɝeɪɾɪŋ.

Elayne settled herself in Glimmer's saddle. The mare was one of the prizes of the royal stable; she was of fine Saldaean stock with a brilliant white mane and coat. The saddle itself was rich, the leather trimmed with wine-red and gold. It was the sort of saddle you used when parading.

bɝdʒɪt ɹoʊd ɹaɪzɪŋ, ə tɔl dʌn ɡɛldɪŋ, ɔlsoʊ wʌn ə ðə fæstəst ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl steɪbəlz. ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd tʃoʊzən boʊθ hɔɹsəz. ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv tə ɹʌn.

Birgitte rode Rising, a tall dun gelding, also one of the fastest in the royal stables. The Warder had chosen both horses. She expected to have to run.

bɝdʒɪt wɔɹ wʌn ʌv ɪleɪnz fɑkshɛd kɑpiz, ðoʊ ɪt hæɾ ə dɪfɹənt ʃeɪp, ə θɪn sɪlvɝ dɪsk wɪð ə ɹoʊz ɑn ðə fɹʌnt. ɪleɪn kæɹiɾ ənʌðɝ ɹæpt ɪn klɔθ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ pɑkət.

Birgitte wore one of Elayne's foxhead copies, though it had a different shape, a thin silver disc with a rose on the front. Elayne carried another wrapped in cloth inside her pocket.

ʃid tʃɹaɪd meɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd mɛltəd, nɪɹli sɛɾɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛsɝ ɑn faɪɝ. ʃi wɑz hævɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə dɪfəkəlti wɪθaʊt ði ɝɪdʒənəl tə stʌɾi. hɝ dʒɹimz ʌv ɑɹmɪŋ ɔl ə hɝ pɝsənəl ɡɑɹdz wɪð mədæljənz wɑz lʊkɪŋ lɛs ən lɛs pɑsəbəl, ənlɛs ʃi sʌmhaʊ mænədʒ tə pɝsweɪd mæt tə ɡɪv əɹ ði ɝɪdʒənəl əɡɛn.

She'd tried making another this morning, but it had melted, nearly setting her dresser on fire. She was having a great deal of difficulty without the original to study. Her dreams of arming all of her personal Guards with medallions was looking less and less possible, unless she somehow managed to persuade Mat to give her the original again.

hɝ ɑnɝ ɡɑɹd fɛl ɪndə maʊntəd ɹæŋks ɝaʊn əɹ ən bɝdʒɪɾ ɪn ðə kwinz plɑzə. ʃi wɑz bɹɪŋɪŋ oʊnli ə hʌnʒɹəd soʊlʒɝz - sɛvənti-faɪv ɡɑɹdzmɪn ən ən ɪnɝ ɹɪŋ ə twɛnti-faɪv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən. ɪt wɑz ə taɪni fɔɹs, bʌt ʃiɾ əv ɡɔn wɪθaʊt ðoʊz hʌnʒɹəd ɪf ʃid bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð ɪt. ʃi kʊdn əfɔɹd tə bi sin əz ə kɑŋkɝɝ.

Her honor guard fell into mounted ranks around her and Birgitte in the Queen's Plaza. She was bringing only a hundred soldiers - seventy-five Guardsmen and an inner ring of twenty-five Guardswomen. It was a tiny force, but she'd have gone without those hundred if she'd been able to get away with it. She couldn't afford to be seen as a conqueror.

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs," bɝdʒɪt sɛd.

"I don't like this," Birgitte said.

"ju doʊn laɪk ɛniθɪŋ, leɪtli," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ swɛɹ, jəɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ ɪɹəɾəbəl baɪ ðə deɪ."

"You don't like anything, lately," Elayne said. "I swear, you're becoming more irritable by the day."

"ɪts kəz jəɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ fulhɑɹɾi baɪ ðə deɪ."

"It's because you're becoming more foolhardy by the day."

"oʊ, kʌm naʊ. ðɪs ɪz hɑɹdli ðə moʊs fulhɑɹɾi θɪŋ aɪv dʌn."

"Oh, come now. This is hardly the most foolhardy thing I've done."

"oʊnli kəz juv sɛɾ ə vɛɹi haɪ bɛntʃmɑɹk fəɹ jɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn "

"Only because you've set a very high benchmark for yourself, Elayne "

"ɪt wɪl bi faɪn," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ saʊθwɝd.

"It will be fine," Elayne said, glancing southward.

"waɪ dʒju kip lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən?"

"Why do you keep looking in that direction?"

"ɹænd," ɪleɪn sɛd, filɪŋ ðət wɔɹmθ əɡɛn, pʌlsɪŋ fɹəm ðə nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn əɹ maɪnd.

"Rand," Elayne said, feeling that warmth again, pulsing from the knot of emotions in her mind.

"hiz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ. hi filz tʃɹʌbəld. ən pisfəl ət ðə seɪm taɪm." laɪt, bʌt ðət mæn kəd bi kənfjuzɪŋ.

"He's getting ready for something. He feels troubled. And peaceful at the same time." Light, but that man could be confusing.

ðə miɾɪŋ wəd hæpən ɪn wʌn deɪ, ɪf ɪz ɝɪdʒənəl dɛdlaɪn stɪl hɛld. ɛɡwin wɑz ɹaɪt;

The meeting would happen in one day, if his original deadline still held. Egwene was right;

bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə silz wəd bi fulɪʃ. bʌt ɹænd wəd si ɹizən.

breaking the seals would be foolish. But Rand would see reason.

æləz ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə hɝ, əkʌmpənid baɪ θɹi kɪnswɪmən. sɑɹeɪʒə wɑz ə plʌmp wʊmən wɪð ə ɡɹændmʌðɝli ɛɹ; dɑɹk-skɪn kimə kɛpt əɹ blæk hɛɹ ɪn θɹi lɔŋ bɹeɪdz, ən pɹɪm næʃiə wɪð ə juθfəl feɪs wɔɹ ə bæɡi dʒɹɛs.

Alise rode up to her, accompanied by three Kinswomen. Sarasia was a plump woman with a grandmotherly air; dark-skinned Kema kept her black hair in three long braids, and prim Nashia with a youthful face wore a baggy dress.

ðə fɔɹ tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃənz bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪn. oʊnli tu ʌv əm wɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə ɡeɪtweɪ -  mɛni ʌv ðə kɪn wɝ wikɝ ðən moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ðət wəd bi ɪnʌf, əsumɪŋ ɪleɪn hæd tʃɹʌbəl ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs.

The four took up positions beside Elayne. Only two of them were strong enough for a gateway -  many of the Kin were weaker than most Aes Sedai. But that would be enough, assuming Elayne had trouble embracing the Source.

"kæn jə də sʌmθɪŋ tə pɹɪvɛn ɑɹtʃɝz fɹəm hɪɾɪŋ hɝ?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt æləz. "sʌm kaɪndə wiv?"

"Can you do something to prevent archers from hitting her?" Birgitte asked Alise. "Some kind of weave?"

æləz kɑkt əɹ hɛd θɔtfəli. "aɪ noʊ ʌv wʌn ðət maɪt hɛlp," ʃi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪv nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪɾ ɪt."

Alise cocked her head thoughtfully. "I know of one that might help," she said, "but I've never tried it."

ənʌðɝ kɪnswʊmən woʊv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ʌp əhɛd. ɪɾ oʊpən tə ə spæn ə ɹʌf, bɹaʊn-ɡɹæs læn aʊtsaɪɾ ə kɛɹhin. ə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ɑɹmi weɪɾəd ðɛɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ðə kwɪɹæsəz ən bɛl-ʃeɪp hɛlməts ə kɛɹhinɪn tʃɹups. ði ɔfəsɝz wɝ izi tə spɑt wɪð ðɛɹ dɑɹk kloʊðɪŋ, ɪn ðə kʌlɝz ə ðə haʊsəz ðeɪ sɝvd. ðeɪ wɔɹ kɑn ɹaɪzɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ bæks.

Another Kinswoman wove a gateway up ahead. It opened to a span of rough, brown-grassed land outside of Cairhien. A much larger army waited there, wearing the cuirasses and bell-shaped helmets of Cairhienin troops. The officers were easy to spot with their dark clothing, in the colors of the Houses they served. They wore con rising over their backs.

tɔl, nɛɹoʊ-feɪs lɔɹstʃɹəm sæɾ ɪz maʊn ət ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz ɑɹmi, wɪtʃ wɔɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin wɪð kɹɪmzən slæʃɪz; bɝtoʊm wɑz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ðɛɹ fɔɹsɪz lʊk tə bi əbaʊt ðə seɪm saɪz. faɪv θaʊzən itʃ. ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ haʊsəz hæd fildɪd smɔlɝ ɑɹmiz.

Tall, narrow-faced Lorstrum sat his mount at the front of his army, which wore dark green with crimson slashes; Bertome was on the other side. Their forces looked to be about the same size. Five thousand each. The other four Houses had fielded smaller armies.

"ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd tə teɪk jə kæptɪv," bɝdʒɪt sɛd ɡɹɪmli, "jɔɹ hændɪŋ əm ðə tʃæns."

"If they wanted to take you captive," Birgitte said grimly, "you're handing them the chance."

"ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ tə də ðɪs ən ɹɪmeɪn seɪf, nɑɾ ənlɛs aɪ wɑnə haɪɾ ɪn maɪ pæləs ən sɛn maɪ tʃɹups ɪn. ðət wəɾ oʊnli lɛd tə ɹɪbɛljən ɪn kɛɹhin ən pətɛnʃəl kəlæps ɪn ændɝ." ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ. "aɪm kwin naʊ, bɝdʒɪt. jəɹ nɑt gɑnə bi eɪbəl tə kip mi fɹəm deɪnʒɝ, noʊ mɔɹ ðən jə kəd kip ə loʊn soʊlʒɝ seɪf ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild."

"There's no way to do this and remain safe, not unless I want to hide in my palace and send my troops in. That would only lead to rebellion in Cairhien and potential collapse in Andor." She glanced at the Warder. "I'm Queen now, Birgitte. You're not going to be able to keep me from danger, no more than you could keep a lone soldier safe on the battlefield."

bɝdʒɪt nɑɾəd. "steɪ kloʊs tə mi ən ɡaɪbɑn."

Birgitte nodded. "Stay close to me and Guybon."

ɡaɪbɑn əpɹoʊtʃt, ɑn ə lɑɹdʒ dæpəld ɡɛldɪŋ. wɪð bɝdʒɪɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə hɝ ən ɡaɪbɑn ɑn ði ʌðɝ - ən wɪð boʊθ ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz tɔlɝ ðən ɪleɪnz - ə wʊd-bi əsæsən wəɾ əv ɡɹeɪt dɪfəkəlti pɪkɪŋ əɹ ɔf wɪθaʊt fɝs hɪɾɪŋ əɹ fɹɛnz.

Guybon approached, on a large dappled gelding. With Birgitte on one side of her and Guybon on the other - and with both of their horses taller than Elayne's - a would-be assassin would have great difficulty picking her off without first hitting her friends.

soʊ ɪt wəd bi fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf. ʃi nʌdʒd ɡlɪmɝ ɪndə moʊʃən, ən əɹ tʃɹup meɪɾ ɪts weɪ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ən ɑntu kɛɹhinɪn sɔɪl. ðə noʊbəlmən ən noʊbəlwɪmən əhɛd baʊɾ əɹ kɝtsid fɹəm hɔɹsbæk, ən ðoʊz ɑbleɪʃənz wɝ dipɝ ðɪs taɪm ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪn wən miɾɪŋ ɪleɪn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊn ɹum. ðə ʃoʊ hæd bɪɡʌn.

So it would be for the rest of her life. She nudged Glimmer into motion, and her troop made its way through the gateway and onto Cairhienin soil. The noblemen and noblewomen ahead bowed or curtsied from horseback, and those oblations were deeper this time than they had been when meeting Elayne in her throne room. The show had begun.

ðə sɪɾi wɑz dʒʌst əhɛd, wɔlz stɪl blækən fɹəm faɪɝz dʊɹɪŋ ðə faɪt wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ɪleɪn kəd sɛns bɝdʒɪts tɛnʃən əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃt bɪhaɪnd. ðə kɪn ɝaʊn ɪleɪn ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, ən æləz woʊv ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ wiv, pleɪsɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ði ɪnɝ ɹɪŋ ə tʃɹups. ɪt meɪɾ ə smɔl - bʌt swɪft - wɪn spɪnɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

The city was just ahead, walls still blackened from fires during the fight with the Shaido. Elayne could sense Birgitte's tension as the gateway vanished behind. The Kin around Elayne embraced the source, and Alise wove an unfamiliar weave, placing it in the air around the inner ring of troops. It made a small - but swift - wind spinning in the air.

bɝdʒɪts æŋzaɪəɾi wɑz kənteɪdʒəs, ən ɪleɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz ɪn ə taɪt ɡɹɪp əz ɡlɪmɝ muv fɔɹwɝd. ði ɛɹ wɑz dʒɹaɪɝ hɪɹ ɪn kɛɹhin, wɪð ə feɪn dʌsti sɛn tə ɪt. ðə skaɪ wɑz oʊvɝkæst.

Birgitte's anxiety was contagious, and Elayne found herself holding her reins in a tight grip as Glimmer moved forward. The air was drier here in Cairhien, with a faint dusty scent to it. The sky was overcast.

ðə kɛɹhinɪn tʃɹups fɔɹmd ɝaʊn əɹ smɔl ɡɹup ʌv ændɔɹənz ɪn waɪɾ ən ɹɛd. moʊst ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn fɔɹsɪz wɝ fʊt, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz səm hɛvi kævəlɹi, hɔɹsəz ɪn ʃaɪni bɑɹɾɪŋ ən mɛn kæɹiɪŋ lænsɪz pɔɪntəd haɪ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ɔl mɑɹtʃt ɪn pɝfək laɪnz, pɹətɛktɪŋ ɪleɪn. əɹ kipɪŋ əɹ kæptɪv.

The Cairhienin troops formed around her small group of Andorans in white and red. Most of the Cairhienin forces were foot, though there was some heavy cavalry, horses in shiny barding and men carrying lances pointed high into the air. All marched in perfect lines, protecting Elayne. Or keeping her captive.

lɔɹstʃɹəm muvd ɪz beɪ stæljən kloʊsɝ tə ɪleɪnz aʊɾɝ ɹæŋks. ɡaɪbɑn ɡlænst ət hɝ, ən ʃi nɑɾəd, soʊ ðə kæptən əlaʊɾ ɪm tə əpɹoʊtʃ.

Lorstrum moved his bay stallion closer to Elayne's outer ranks. Guybon glanced at her, and she nodded, so the captain allowed him to approach.

"ðə sɪɾi ɪz nɝvəs, jəɹ mædʒəsti," lɔɹstʃɹəm sɛd. bɝdʒɪt wɑz stɪl kɛɹfəl tə kip əɹ maʊn bɪtwin ɪz ən ɪleɪnz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ . . . ənfɔɹtʃənət ɹumɝz sɝaʊndɪŋ jəɹ əsɛnʃən."

"The city is nervous, Your Majesty," Lorstrum said. Birgitte was still careful to keep her mount between his and Elayne's. "There are . . . unfortunate rumors surrounding your ascension."

ɹumɝz jə pɹɑbli ɪnɪʃieɪɾəd, ɪleɪn θɔt, bɪfɔɹ jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə səpɔɹt mi ɪnstɛd. "ʃʊɹli ðeɪ woʊn ɹaɪz əɡɛns jəɹ tʃɹups?"

Rumors you probably initiated, Elayne thought, before you decided to support me instead. "Surely they won't rise against your troops?"

"aɪ hoʊp ðəl nɑt." hi aɪɾ əɹ fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz flæt kæp ə fɔɹəst ɡɹin. hi wɔɹ ə blæk koʊt ðət wɛn daʊn tə hɪz niz ən slæʃɪz ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs ɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn, tə dɪnoʊɾ ɪz haʊs. ɪt wɑz ðə taɪp ə kloʊðɪŋ hid wɛɹ ɪf ɡoʊɪŋ tə ə bɔl. ðət pɹədʒɛktəɾ ə sɛns ə kɑnfəɾəns. hɪz fɔɹs wɑzn sizɪŋ ðə sɪɾi, ɪt wɑz ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ ðə nu kwin wɪð ən ɑnɝɛɹi pɝeɪd. "ɪɾ ɪz ənlaɪkli ðət ðəɹ wɪl bi ɑɹmd ɹɪzɪstəns. bʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd tə wɔɹn ju."

"I hope they will not." He eyed her from under his flat cap of forest green. He wore a black coat that went down to his knees and slashes of color across it all the way down, to denote his House. It was the type of clothing he'd wear if going to a ball. That projected a sense of confidence. His force wasn't seizing the city, it was escorting the new queen with an honorary parade. "It is unlikely that there will be armed resistance. But I wanted to warn you."

lɔɹstʃɹəm nɑɾəd tə hɝ wɪð ɹɪspɛkt. hi nu ʃi wɑz mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ hɪm, bʌɾ i ɔlsoʊ æksɛptɪd ðət mənɪpjəleɪʃən. ʃi wəɾ əv tə kip ə kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ ɑn ɪm ɪn ðə jɪɹz tə kʌm.

Lorstrum nodded to her with respect. He knew she was manipulating him, but he also accepted that manipulation. She would have to keep a careful watch on him in the years to come.

kɛɹhin wɑz sətʃ ə bɑksɪʃ sɪɾi, ɔl stʃɹeɪt laɪnz ən fɔɹɾəfaɪd taʊɝz. ðoʊ səm ʌv ɪts ɑɹkətɛktʃɝ wɑz bjuɾəfəl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kəmpɛɹɪŋ ðə pleɪs tə keɪɛmlɪn əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðeɪ ɹoʊd dɝɛkli ɪn θɹu ðə nɔɹðɝn ɡeɪts, ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑlɡnjə tə ðɛɹ ɹaɪt.

Cairhien was such a boxish city, all straight lines and fortified towers. Though some of its architecture was beautiful, there was no comparing the place to Caemlyn or Tar Valon. They rode directly in through the northern gates, the River Alguenya to their right.

kɹaʊdz weɪɾəd ɪnsaɪd. lɔɹstʃɹəm ən ði ʌðɝz hæd dʌn ðɛɹ wɝk wɛl. ðəɹ wɝ tʃɪɹz, pɹɑbli stɑɹɾəd baɪ kɛɹfəli pleɪs kɔɹɾiɝz. əz ɪleɪn ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi, ðə tʃɪɹz ɡɹu laʊɾɝ.

Crowds waited inside. Lorstrum and the others had done their work well. There were cheers, probably started by carefully placed courtiers. As Elayne entered the city, the cheers grew louder.

ðət sɝpɹaɪz hɝ. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd hɑstɪləɾi. ən jɛs, ðəɹ wɑz səm ə ðət - ði əkeɪʒənəl θɹoʊn pis ə ɹɛfjus, hɝl fɹəm ðə bæk ə ðə kɹaʊd. ʃi kɑɾ ə dʒɪɹ hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ. bʌt moʊst sim plizd.

That surprised her. She had expected hostility. And yes, there was some of that - the occasional thrown piece of refuse, hurled from the back of the crowd. She caught a jeer here and there. But most seemed pleased.

əz ʃi ɹoʊd daʊn ðət bɹɔd pæsədʒweɪ, laɪnd wɪð ðə ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ bɪldɪŋz kɛɹhinɪn feɪvɝd, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət pɝhæps ðiz pipəl hæd bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ɪvɛn laɪk ðɪs. tɔkɪŋ ʌv ɪt, spɹɛɾɪŋ teɪlz. səm ə ðoʊz teɪlz hæd bɪn hɑstəl, ən ðoʊz wɝ wʌt nɔɹi hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd. bʌt ðeɪ naʊ sim tə hɝ mɔɹ ə saɪn ʌv wɝi ðən hɑstɪləɾi. kɛɹhin hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə mɑnɑɹk, ðɛɹ kɪŋ dɛd baɪ ənnoʊn hænz, ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən simɪŋli əbændənɪŋ ðɛm.

As she rode down that broad passageway, lined with the rectangular buildings Cairhienin favored, she realized that perhaps these people had been waiting for an event like this. Talking of it, spreading tales. Some of those tales had been hostile, and those were what Norry had reported. But they now seemed to her more a sign of worry than hostility. Cairhien had been too long without a monarch, their king dead by unknown hands, the Lord Dragon seemingly abandoning them.

hɝ kɑnfəɾəns ɡɹu. kɛɹhin wɑz ə wundəd sɪɾi. ðə bɝn ən bɹoʊkən ɹɛmnəns ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪɾ aʊtsaɪd. kɑbəlz hæd bɪn tɔɹn ʌp tə bi θɹoʊn fɹəm ðə wɔlz. ðə sɪɾi hæd nɛvɝ fʊli ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm ði il wɔɹ, ən ði ənfɪnɪʃt tɑpləs taʊɝz - səmɛtʃɹɪkəl ɪn dɪzaɪn, bʌt woʊfəli fɝlɔɹn ɪn əpɪɹəns - wɝ ə lɔfti dɛklɝeɪʃən ə ðət fækt.

Her confidence grew. Cairhien was a wounded city. The burned and broken remnants of the Foregate outside. Cobbles had been torn up to be thrown from the walls. The city had never fully recovered from the Aiel War, and the unfinished Topless Towers - symmetrical in design, but woefully forlorn in appearance - were a lofty declaration of that fact.

ðət blʌɾi ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz wɑz nɪɹli əz bæɾ ə skɝdʒ. kəd ʃi tʃeɪnʒ ðæt? ðə pipəl ɝaʊn əɹ saʊndəd hoʊpfəl, əz ɪf ðeɪ nu wʌɾ ə twɪstəd mɛs ðɛɹ neɪʃən hæd bɪkʌm. wʌn kəd sunɝ teɪk əweɪ ən ilz spɪɹz ðən kʌt ðə kɹæftinəs aʊɾ ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn, bʌt pɝhæps ʃi kəd titʃ əm ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ lɔɪəlti tə kʌntʃɹi ən θɹoʊn. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ hæɾ ə θɹoʊn wɝθ ðət lɔɪəlti.

That bloody Game of Houses was nearly as bad a scourge. Could she change that? The people around her sounded hopeful, as if they knew what a twisted mess their nation had become. One could sooner take away an Aiel's spears than cut the craftiness out of the Cairhienin, but perhaps she could teach them a greater loyalty to country and throne. So long as they had a throne worth that loyalty.

ðə sʌn pæləs stʊɾ ət ði ɪɡzæk sɛntɝ ə ðə sɪɾi. laɪk ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sɪɾi, ɪt wɑz skwɛɹ ən æŋɡjəlɝ, bʌt hɪɹ ði ɑɹkətɛktʃɝ ɡeɪv ə sɛns əɹ ɪmpoʊzɪŋ stʃɹɛŋkθ. ɪt wɑz ə ɡɹæn bɪldɪŋ, dɪspaɪt ðə bɹoʊkən wɪŋ wɛɹ ði ətɛmpt ɑn ɹændz laɪf hæd teɪkən pleɪs.

The Sun Palace stood at the exact center of the city. Like the rest of the city, it was square and angular, but here the architecture gave a sense or imposing strength. It was a grand building, despite the broken wing where the attempt on Rand's life had taken place.

mɔɹ noʊbəlz weɪɾəd hɪɹ, stændɪŋ ɑn kʌvɝd stɛps əɹ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɔɹneɪt kæɹɪdʒɪz. wɪmən ɪn fɔɹməl ɡaʊnz wɪð waɪd hups, ðə mɛn ɪn nit koʊts ə dɑɹk kʌlɝz, kæps ɑn ðə hɛdz. mɛni lʊk skɛptəkəl, ən səm əmeɪzd.

More nobles waited here, standing on covered steps or in front of ornate carriages. Women in formal gowns with wide hoops, the men in neat coats of dark colors, caps on the heads. Many looked skeptical, and some amazed.

ɪleɪn ʃɑt bɝdʒɪɾ ə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl. "ɪts wɝkɪŋ. noʊbɑdi ɪkspɛktəd mi tə ɹaɪd tə ðə pæləs ɛskɔɹɾɪd baɪ ə kɛɹhinɪn ɑɹmi."

Elayne shot Birgitte a satisfied smile. "It's working. Nobody expected me to ride to the palace escorted by a Cairhienin army."

bɝdʒɪt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ʃi wɑz stɪl tɛns - ən pɹɑbli wəd bi əntɪl ɪleɪn ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn.

Birgitte said nothing. She was still tense - and probably would be until Elayne returned to Caemlyn.

tu wɪmən stʊɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛps, wʌn ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪð bɛlz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ði ʌðɝ wɪð kɝli hɛɹ ən ə feɪs ðət dɪd nɑt sim ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ ɔl ðə fæk ðət ʃi hæd bɪn wʌn fəɹ jɪɹz.

Two women stood at the foot of the steps, one a pretty woman with bells in her hair, the other with curly hair and a face that did not seem Aes Sedai, for all the fact that she had been one for years.

ðət wɑz sæʃəl ændɝli, ən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən - hu dɪɾ əv ən eɪdʒləs feɪs - wɑz sæmɪtsu tɑmɑɡoʊə. fɹəm wʌɾ ɪleɪnz sɔɹsəz hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə dətɝmən, ðiz tu wɝ əz kloʊz tə "ɹulɝz" əz ðə sɪɾi hæɾ ɪn ɹændz æbsəns. ʃid kɔɹəspɑndɪd wɪð boʊθ, ən faʊn sæʃəl ɹɪmɑɹkəbli kin əɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ ðə kɛɹhinɪn weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ. ʃiɾ ɔfɝɾ ɪleɪn ðə sɪɾi, bʌt hæɾ ɪmplaɪd ðət ʃi ʌndɝstʊd ðət biɪŋ ɔfɝɾ ɪɾ ən teɪkɪŋ ɪt wɝ tu dɪfɹən θɪŋz.

That was Sashalle Anderly, and the other woman - who did have an ageless face - was Samitsu Tamagowa. From what Elayne's sources had been able to determine, these two were as close to "rulers" as the city had in Rand's absence. She'd corresponded with both, and found Sashalle remarkably keen at understanding the Cairhienin way of thinking. She'd offered Elayne the city, but had implied that she understood that being offered it and taking it were two different things.

sæʃəl stɛp fɔɹwɝd. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti," ʃi sɛd fɔɹməli, "lɛɾ ɪt bi noʊn ðət ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɡɪvz jə ɔl ɹaɪts ən kleɪm tə ðɪs lænd. ɔl fɔɹməl kəntʃɹoʊl i hæɾ oʊvɝ ðə læn ɪz siɾəd tə ju, ən ðə pəzɪʃən ə stuɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə neɪʃən ɪz dɪzɑlvd. meɪ jə ɹul ɪn wɪzdəm ən pis."

Sashalle stepped forward. "Your Majesty," she said formally, "let it be known that the Lord Dragon gives you all rights and claim to this land. All formal control he had over the land is ceded to you, and the position of steward over the nation is dissolved. May you rule in wisdom and peace."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd tə hɝ ɹiɡəli fɹəm hɔɹsbæk, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪd ʃi siðd. ʃid sɛd ʃi dɪdn maɪn ɹændz hɛlp teɪkɪŋ ðɪs θɹoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn laɪk ʃi wɑntəɾ əɹ noʊz ɹʌbd ɪn ɪt. stɪl, sæʃəl sim tə teɪk əɹ pəzɪʃən sɪɹiəsli, ðoʊ fɹəm wʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd dɪskʌvɝd, ðət pəzɪʃən wɑz ɪn lɑɹdʒ mɛʒɝ sɛlf-kɹieɪɾəd.

Elayne nodded to her regally from horseback, but inside she seethed. She'd said she didn't mind Rand's help taking this throne, but it wasn't like she wanted her nose rubbed in it. Still, Sashalle seemed to take her position seriously, though from what Elayne had discovered, that position was in large measure self-created.

ɪleɪn ən əɹ pɹəsɛʃən dɪsmaʊntɪd. hæd ɹænd θɔt ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi əz izi əz ðət tə ɡɪv əɹ ðə θɹoʊn? hid steɪɾ ɪn kɛɹhin lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə noʊ haʊ ðeɪ skimd. wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪkɪŋ ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən wəd nɛvɝ əv bɪn ɪnʌf. bʌt hævɪŋ paʊɝfəl noʊbəlz səpɔɹɾ əɹ dɝɛkli ʃəd bi ɪnʌf tə də ɪt.

Elayne and her procession dismounted. Had Rand thought that it would be as easy as that to give her the throne? He'd stayed in Cairhien long enough to know how they schemed. One Aes Sedai making a proclamation would never have been enough. But having powerful nobles support her directly should be enough to do it.

ðɛɹ pɹəsɛʃən meɪɾ ɪts weɪ ʌp ðə stɛps. ðeɪ ɛntɝd, ən itʃ ə ðoʊz səpɔɹɾɪŋ əɹ bɹɔɾ ə smɔlɝ ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ ə fɪfti. ɪleɪn bɹɔɾ əɹ ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹs; ɪt wɑz kɹaʊɾəd, bʌt ʃi dɪdn ɪntɛn tə liv ɛni bɪhaɪnd.

Their procession made its way up the steps. They entered, and each of those supporting her brought a smaller honor guard of fifty. Elayne brought her entire force; it was crowded, but she didn't intend to leave any behind.

ði ɪnɝ hɔlweɪz wɝ stʃɹeɪt, wɪð pik silɪŋz ən ɡoʊldən tʃɹɪm. ðə sɪmbəl ə ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ɛmbleɪzən itʃ dɔɹ. ðəɹ wɝ ælkoʊvz fəɹ ɹɪtʃəz tə bi dɪspleɪd, bʌt mɛni wɝ ɛmpti. ði il hæd teɪkən ðɛɹ fɪfθ fɹəm ðɪs pæləs.

The inner hallways were straight, with peaked ceilings and golden trim. The symbol of the Rising Sun emblazoned each door. There were alcoves for riches to be displayed, but many were empty. The Aiel had taken their fifth from this palace.

əpɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl ə ðə sʌn, ɪleɪnz ændɔɝən ɡɑɹdzmɪn ən ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɝeɪnʒd ðɛmsɛlvz laɪnɪŋ ði aʊɾɝ hɔlweɪ. ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum wɪð ə ɡɹup ə tɛn. blu-stʃɹik mɑɹbəl kɑləmz ɹoʊz tə ðə silɪŋ ət ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹum, ən ðə sʌn θɹoʊn sæɾ ɑn ɪts blu mɑɹbəl deɪz ət ðə bæk ə ðə lɑɹdʒ hɔl.

Upon reaching the entrance to the Grand Hall of the Sun, Elayne's Andoran Guardsmen and Guardswomen arranged themselves lining the outer hallway. Elayne took a deep breath, then strode into the throne room with a group of ten. Blue-streaked marble columns rose to the ceiling at the sides of the room, and the Sun Throne sat on its blue marble dais at the back of the large hall.

ðə sit wɑz ʌv ɡɪldɪd wʊd, bʌt wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli ʌnəsumɪŋ. pɝhæps ðət wɑz waɪ leɪmən hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɪl hɪmsɛlf ə nu θɹoʊn, juzɪŋ ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə ɪtsɛlf əz ə mətɪɹiəl. ɪleɪn wɔkt ʌp tə ðə deɪz, ðən tɝn əz ðə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbɪləɾi ɛntɝd, hɝ səpɔɹɾɝz fɝst, ðən ði ʌðɝz, ɹæŋkt əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə kɑmpləkeɪɾəd dɪkteɪts ə dʌz deɪmɑɹ. ðoʊz ɹæŋkɪŋz kəd tʃeɪnʒ baɪ ðə deɪ, ɪf nɑt ði aʊɝ.

The seat was of gilded wood, but was surprisingly unassuming. Perhaps that was why Laman had decided to build himself a new throne, using Avendoraldera itself as a material. Elayne walked up to the dais, then turned as the Cairhienin nobility entered, her supporters first, then the others, ranked according to the complicated dictates of Does Dae'mar. Those rankings could change by the day, if not the hour.

bɝdʒɪɾ aɪɾ itʃ wʌn u ɛntɝd, bʌt ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɝ mɑɾəlz ə pɹəpɹaɪəɾi. nʌn wəd ʃoʊ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɛlɹinz ɑdæsəɾi ɪn ændɝ. ʃi wɑz ə peɪtʃɹiət, ɪf wʌn u fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋli kəntɪnjud tə dɪsəɡɹi wɪð ɪleɪn. ɪn kɛɹhin, wʌn dɪd nɑt də sətʃ θɪŋz.

Birgitte eyed each one who entered, but the Cairhienin were models of propriety. None would show anything like Ellorien's audacity in Andor. She was a patriot, if one who frustratingly continued to disagree with Elayne. In Cairhien, one did not do such things.

wʌns ðə kɹaʊd hæd stɪld, ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃid kənsɪɾɝd ə spitʃ, bʌɾ əɹ mʌðɝ hæd tɔɾ əɹ ðət səmtaɪmz, dɪsaɪsɪv ækʃən meɪd fəɹ ðə bɛst spitʃ. ɪleɪn muv tə sɪt daʊn ɪn ðə θɹoʊn.

Once the crowd had stilled, Elayne took a deep breath. She'd considered a speech, but her mother had taught her that sometimes, decisive action made for the best speech. Elayne moved to sit down in the throne.

bɝdʒɪt kɑɾ əɹ ɑɹm.

Birgitte caught her arm.

ɪleɪn ɡlænst əɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋli, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz aɪɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn. "weɪɾ ə moʊmənt," ʃi sɛd, bɛndɪŋ daʊn.

Elayne glanced at her questioningly, but the Warder was eyeing the throne. "Wait a moment," she said, bending down.

ðə noʊbəlz bɪɡæn mɝmɝɪŋ wʌn tə ənʌðɝ, ən lɔɹstʃɹəm stɛpt ʌp tə ɪleɪn. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti?"

The nobles began murmuring one to another, and Lorstrum stepped up to Elayne. "Your Majesty?"

"bɝdʒɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd, blʌʃɪŋ, "ɪz ðɪs ɹɪli nɛsəsɛɹi?"

"Birgitte," Elayne said, blushing, "is this really necessary?"

bɝdʒɪɾ ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ, pɹɑɾɪŋ ət ðə sits kʊʃən. laɪt! wɑz ðə wɔɹɾɝ dɪtɝmən tə ɪmbɛɹəs əɹ ɪn ɛvɹi pɑsəbəl sɪtʃueɪʃən? ʃʊɹli ði -  "ɑhɑ!" bɝdʒɪt sɛd, jæŋkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə pɪloʊd kʊʃən.

Birgitte ignored her, prodding at the seat's cushion. Light! Was the Warder determined to embarrass her in every possible situation? Surely the -  "Aha!" Birgitte said, yanking something from the pillowed cushion.

ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd, ðə stɛp kloʊsɝ, lɔɹstʃɹəm ən bɝtoʊm əɾ əɹ saɪd. bɝdʒɪt wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə smɔl niɾəl, tɪp blæk. "hɪɾən ɪn ðə kʊʃən."

Elayne started, the stepped closer, Lorstrum and Bertome at her side. Birgitte was holding up a small needle, tipped black. "Hidden in the cushion."

ɪleɪn peɪld.

Elayne paled.

"ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli pleɪs ðeɪ nu jud bi, ɪleɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd sɔfli. ʃi nɛl daʊn ən bɪɡæn pɹɑɾɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ tʃɹæps.
