"It was the only place they knew you'd be, Elayne," Birgitte said softly. She knelt down and began prodding for more traps.

lɔɹstʃɹəm hæd ɡɹoʊn flʌʃt. "aɪ wɪl faɪn u dɪd ðɪs, jəɹ mædʒəsti," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. ə deɪnʒɝəs vɔɪs. "ðeɪ wɪl noʊ maɪ ɹæθ."

Lorstrum had grown flushed. "I will find who did this, Your Majesty," he said in a low voice. A dangerous voice. "They will know my wrath."

"nɑɾ ɪf ðeɪ noʊ maɪn fɝst," stɑki bɝtoʊm sɛd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə niɾəl.

"Not if they know mine first," stocky Bertome said, looking over the needle.

"ɑbviəsli ən əsæsəneɪʃən ətɛmpt ɪntɛndəd fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, jəɹ mædʒəsti," lɔɹstʃɹəm sɛɾ ɪn ə laʊɾɝ vɔɪs, fəɹ ðə bɛnəfɪɾ ə ði ɑɾiəns. "nʌn wəd dɛɹ tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl ju, əɹ bɪlʌv sɪstɝ fɹəm ændɝ."

"Obviously an assassination attempt intended for the Lord Dragon, Your Majesty," Lorstrum said in a louder voice, for the benefit of the audience. "None would dare try to kill you, our beloved sister from Andor."

"ðæɾ ɪz ɡʊd tə hɪɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd, aɪɪŋ hɪm. ðəɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən ə hɝz sɛd tə ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə ɹum ðət ʃi wəd pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðɪs ɹuz, ɪntɛndəd tə seɪv ɪz feɪs. əz əɹ stʃɹɔŋɡəst səpɔɹɾɝ, ðə ʃeɪm ʌv ən əsæsəneɪʃən ətɛmp fɛl ɑn hɪm.

"That is good to hear," Elayne said, eyeing him. That expression of hers said to everyone in the room that she would put up with this ruse, intended to save his face. As her strongest supporter, the shame of an assassination attempt fell on him.

əɡɹiɪŋ tə lɛɾ ɪm seɪv feɪs wəd kɑs hɪm. hi loʊɝɾ ɪz aɪz bɹifli ɪn ʌndɝstændɪŋ.

Agreeing to let him save face would cost him. He lowered his eyes briefly in understanding.

laɪt, ʃi heɪɾəd ðɪs ɡeɪm. bʌt ʃi wəd pleɪ ɪt. ən ʃi wəd pleɪ ɪt wɛl.

Light, she hated this game. But she would play it. And she would play it well.

"ɪz ɪt seɪf?" ʃi æsk bɝdʒɪt.

"Is it safe?" she asked Birgitte.

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɹʌbd əɹ tʃɪn. "wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt," ʃi sɛd, ðən plɑp hɝsɛlf daʊn ɪn ðə θɹoʊn wɪð ən ʌnsɛɹəmoʊniəs əmaʊn ə fɔɹs.

The Warder rubbed her chin. "One way to find out," she said, then plopped herself down in the throne with an unceremonious amount of force.

nɑɾ ə fju ʌv ðə noʊbəlz ɪn ðə hɔl ɡæspt, ən lɔɹstʃɹəm ɡɹu mɔɹ peɪl.

Not a few of the nobles in the hall gasped, and Lorstrum grew more pale.

"nɑt vɛɹi kʌmftəɹbəl," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, linɪŋ tə ðə saɪd, ðən pʊʃɪŋ əɹ bæk ʌp əɡɛns ðə wʊd. "aɪ wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəɾ ə mɑnɑɹks θɹoʊn tə bi mɔɹ kʊʃənd, wʌt wɪð jəɹ dɛləkət bæksaɪɾ ən ɔl."

"Not very comfortable," Birgitte said, leaning to the side, then pushing her back up against the wood. "I would have expected a monarch's throne to be more cushioned, what with your delicate backside and all."

"bɝdʒɪt!" ɪleɪn hɪst, filɪŋ əɹ feɪs ɡɹoʊ ɹɛɾ əɡɛn. "ju kæn sɪɾ ɪn ðə sʌn θɹoʊn!"

"Birgitte!" Elayne hissed, feeling her face grow red again. "You can't sit in the Sun Throne!"

"aɪm jəɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "aɪ kən teɪs jəɹ fuɾ ɪf aɪ wɑnt, aɪ kən wɔk θɹu dɔɹweɪz bɪfɔɹ ju, ən aɪ kən blʌɾi sɪɾ ɪn jəɹ tʃɛɹ ɪf aɪ θɪŋk ɪɾəl pɹətɛk ju." ʃi ɡɹɪnd. "bɪsaɪdz,"

"I'm your bodyguard," Birgitte said. "I can taste your food if I want, I can walk through doorways before you, and I can bloody sit in your chair if I think it will protect you." She grinned. "Besides,"

ʃi æɾəd ɪn ə loʊɝ vɔɪs, "aɪ ɔlweɪz wʌndɝd wʌt wʌn ə ðiz fɛlt laɪk." ðə wɔɹɾɝ stʊɾ ʌp, stɪl wɛɹi, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ sæɾəsfaɪd.

she added in a lower voice, "I always wondered what one of these felt like." The Warder stood up, still wary, but also satisfied.

ɪleɪn tɝn ən feɪs ðə noʊbɪləɾi ʌv kɛɹhin. "ju hæv weɪɾəd lɔŋ fəɹ ðɪs," ʃi sɛd. "sʌm ə jə ɑɹ dɪsæɾəsfaɪd, bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət hæf ə maɪ blʌɾ ɪz kɛɹhinɪn. ðɪs əlaɪəns wɪl meɪk boʊθ ʌv əɹ neɪʃənz ɡɹeɪt. aɪ də nɑt dɪmæn jəɹ tʃɹʌst, bʌɾ aɪ də dɪmæn jəɹ oʊbiɾiəns." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æɾəd, "ɹɪmɛmbɝ əɡɛn, ðɪs ɪz əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪʃɪz ɪt tə bi."

Elayne turned and faced the nobility of Cairhien. "You have waited long for this," she said. "Some of you are dissatisfied, but remember that half of my blood is Cairhienin. This alliance will make both of our nations great. I do not demand your trust, but I do demand your obedience." She hesitated, then added, "Remember again, this is as the Dragon Reborn wishes it to be."

ʃi sɔ ðət ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd. ɹænd hæd kɑŋkɝd ðɪs sɪɾi wʌns, ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn tə lɪbɝeɪɾ ɪt fɹəm ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðeɪ wəd bi waɪz nɑt tə tɛmpt ɪm tə kʌm bæk ən kɑŋkɝ ɪɾ əɡɛn. ə kwin juz ðə tulz ðət ʃi hæɾ ət hænd. ʃi hæd teɪkən ændɝ ɑn əɹ oʊn; ʃi wəd lɛt ɹænd hɛlp əɹ wɪð kɛɹhin.

She saw that they understood. Rand had conquered this city once, though it had been to liberate it from the Shaido. They would be wise not to tempt him to come back and conquer it again. A queen used the tools that she had at hand. She had taken Andor on her own; she would let Rand help her with Cairhien.

ʃi sæt daʊn. sətʃ ə sɪmpəl θɪŋ, bʌt ði ɪmpləkeɪʃənz wəd bi fɑɹ-ɹitʃɪŋ ɪndid. "ɡæðɝ jəɹ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl fɔɹsɪz ən haʊs ɡɑɹdz," ʃi kəmændəd tə ðə kəlɛktəd noʊbəlz. "ju wɪl bi mɑɹtʃɪŋ, wɪð ðə fɔɹsɪz ʌv ændɝ, θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz tə ə pleɪs noʊn əz ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ. wɪl bi miɾɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

She sat down. Such a simple thing, but the implications would be far-reaching indeed. "Gather your individual forces and House guards," she commanded to the collected nobles. "You will be marching, with the forces of Andor, through gateways to a place known as the Field of Merrilor. We will be meeting the Dragon Reborn."

ðə noʊbəlz sim sɝpɹaɪzd. ʃi wəd kʌm ɪn, teɪk ðə θɹoʊn, ðən kəmæn ðɛɹ ɑɹmiz fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ðə seɪm deɪ? ʃi smaɪld. bɛs tə ækt kwɪkli ən dɪsaɪsɪvli; ɪt wəd bɪl pɹɛsɪɾənt fəɹ oʊbeɪɪŋ hɝ. ən wəd bɪɡɪn tə ɹɛɾi ðɛm fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

The nobles seemed surprised. She would come in, take the throne, then command their armies from the city the same day? She smiled. Best to act quickly and decisively; it would build precedent for obeying her. And would begin to ready them for the Last Battle.

"ɔlsoʊ," ʃi ənaʊnst əz ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə wɪspɝ, "aɪ wɑn jə tə ɡæðɝ ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðɪs ɹɛlm u kən hoʊld ə sɔɹɾ ən kɑnskɹɪpt əm ɪndə ðə kwinz ɑɹmi. ðəɹ woʊn bi mʌtʃ taɪm fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn wɪl bi niɾəd ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl - ən ðoʊz wɪmən u wɪʃ tə faɪt meɪ ɹipɔɹɾ əz wɛl. ɔlsoʊ, sɛnd wɝd tə ðə bɛlfndɝz ɪn jəɹ sɪɾi. əl nid tə mit wɪð əm wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ."

"Also," she announced as they began to whisper, "I want you to gather every man in this realm who can hold a sword and conscript them into the Queen's army. There won't be much time for training, but every man will be needed in the Last Battle - and those women who wish to fight may report as well. Also, send word to the bellfounders in your city. I will need to meet with them within the hour."

"bʌt," bɝtoʊm sɛd, "ðə kɔɹəneɪʃən fist, jəɹ mædʒəsti. . . ." "wi wɪl fist wən ðə læs bæɾəl əz bɪn wɝi ən kɛɹhinz tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ seɪf," ɪleɪn sɛd. ʃi niɾəd tə dɪstʃɹækt əm fɹəm ðɛɹ plɑts, ɡɪv əm wɝk tə kip əm bɪzi, ɪf pɑsəbəl. "muv! pɹitɛn ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz ɑn jəɹ dɔɹstɛp, ən wɪl ɝaɪv ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ!" fɔɹ, ɪndiɾ ɪt maɪt.

"But," Bertome said, "the coronation feast, Your Majesty. . . ." "We will feast when the Last Battle has been wori and Cairhien's children are safe," Elayne said. She needed to distract them from their plots, give them work to keep them busy, if possible. "Move! Pretend the Last Battle is on your doorstep, and will arrive on the morrow!" For, indeed it might.

mæt lin əɡɛnst ə dɛd tʃɹi, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz kæmp. hi bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt, smaɪlɪŋ, filɪŋ ðə bjuɾəfəl kʌmfɝɾ ə noʊɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ biɪŋ tʃeɪst. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ ɡʊd ðət fɛlt.

Mat leaned against a dead tree, looking over his camp. He breathed in and out, smiling, feeling the beautiful comfort of knowing that he was no longer being chased. He had forgotten how good that felt.

bɛɾɝ ðən ə pɹɪɾi sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl ɑn itʃ ni, ðət filɪŋ wɑz. wɛl, bɛɾɝ ðən wʌn sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl, ɛniweɪ.

Better than a pretty serving girl on each knee, that feeling was. Well, better than one serving girl, anyway.

ə mɪlətɛɹi kæmp əɾ ivnɪŋ wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊs kʌmftəɹbəl pleɪsəz ɪn ɔl ðə wɝld, ivən ɪf hæf ðə kæmp wɑz ɛmpti, ðə mɛn ðəɹ hævɪŋ ɡɔn tə kɛɹhin. ðə sʌn hæd sɛt, ən səm ə ðoʊz u ɹɪmeɪn hæd tɝn ɪn. bʌt fəɹ ðoʊz u hæd pʊld æftɝnun duɾi ðə nɛks deɪ, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə slip dʒʌs jɛt.

A military camp at evening was one of the most comfortable places in all the world, even if half the camp was empty, the men there having gone to Cairhien. The sun had set, and some of those who remained had turned in. But for those who had pulled afternoon duty the next day, there was no reason to sleep just yet.

ə dʌzən faɪɹɛpɪts smoʊldɝd θɹu ðə kæmp, mɛn sɪɾɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ teɪlz ʌv ɛksplɔɪts, ʌv wɪmən lɛf bɪhaɪnd, əɹ ə ɹumɝz fɹəm fɑɹ ɔf. tʌŋz ə fleɪmz flɪkɝɾ əz mɛn læft, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn lɔɡz əɹ ɹɑks, sʌmwʌn əkeɪʒənəli dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə ðə koʊlz wɪð ə twɪstəd bɹæntʃ ən stɝɪŋ taɪni spɑɹks ɪndə ði ɛɹ əz ɪz fɹɛnz sæŋ "kʌm ji meɪdz" əɹ "fɔlən wɪloʊz ət nun."

A dozen firepits smoldered through the camp, men sitting to share tales of exploits, of women left behind, or of rumors from far off. Tongues of flames flickered as men laughed, sitting on logs or rocks, someone occasionally digging into the coals with a twisted branch and stirring tiny sparks into the air as his friends sang "Come Ye Maids" or "Fallen Willows at Noon."

ðə mɛn ə ðə bænd wɝ fɹəm ə dʌzən dɪfɹənt neɪʃənz, bʌt ðɪs kæmp wɑz ðɛɹ tʃɹu hoʊm. mæt stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðɛm, hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd, æʃhændʒɹeɪ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi hæd ɡɑɾən ə nu skɑɹf fəɹ ɪz nɛk. pipəl nu əbaʊɾ ɪz skɑɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə ʃoʊ ɪɾ ɔf laɪk wʌn əɹ lukəz blʌɾi wæɡənz.

The men of the Band were from a dozen different nations, but this camp was their true home. Mat strode through them, hat on his head, ashandarei over his shoulder. He had gotten a new scarf for his neck. People knew about his scar, but there was no reason to show it off like one or Luca's bloody wagons.

ðə skɑɹf i hæd tʃoʊzən ðɪs taɪm wɑz ɹɛd. ɪn mɛmɹi ʌv taɪlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz u hæd fɔlən tə ðə ɡoʊləm. fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm, hi hæd bɪn tɛmptəd tə tʃuz pɪŋk. ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt taɪm.

The scarf he had chosen this time was red. In memory of Tylin and the others who had fallen to the gholam. For a short time, he had been tempted to choose pink. A very short time.

mæt smaɪld. ðoʊ sɔŋz ɹæŋ fɹəm sɛvɹəl ə ðə kæmpfaɪɝz, nʌn wɝ laʊd, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə hɛlθi stɪlnəs əbaʊt ðə kæmp. nɑɾ ə saɪləns. saɪləns wɑz nɛvɝ ɡʊd. hi heɪɾəd saɪləns. meɪɾ ɪm wʌndɝ u wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd tə snik ʌp ɑn hɪm. noʊ, ðɪs wɑz ə stɪlnəs. mɛn snɔɹɪŋ sɔfli, faɪɝz kɹæklɪŋ, ʌðɝ mɛn sɪŋɪŋ, widz kɹʌntʃɪŋ əz ðoʊz ɑn wɑtʃ pæs baɪ. ðə pisfəl nɔɪzɪz ə mɛn ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðɛɹ laɪvz.

Mat smiled. Though songs rang from several of the campfires, none were loud, and there was a healthy stillness about the camp. Not a silence. Silence was never good. He hated silence. Made him wonder who was trying so hard to sneak up on him. No, this was a stillness. Men snoring softly, fires crackling, other men singing, weeds crunching as those on watch passed by. The peaceful noises of men enjoying their lives.

mæt faʊn ɪz weɪ bæk tə hɪz teɪbəl aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz dɑɹkən tɛnt. hi sæt daʊn, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə peɪpɝz i hæd stæk hɪɹ. ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə tɛn hæd bɪn tu stʌfi. bɪsaɪdz, hi hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə weɪk oʊlvɝ.

Mat found his way back to his table outside his darkened tent. He sat down, looking over the papers he had stacked here. The inside of the tent had been too stuffy. Besides, he had not wanted to wake Olver.

mæts tɛn ɹɪpəld ɪn ðə waɪnd. hɪz sit dɪd lʊk ɑd, ðə faɪn oʊk teɪbəl sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə pætʃ ə hɛnzfʊt, mæts tʃɛɹ bɪsaɪɾ ɪt, ə pɪtʃɝ ə mʌl saɪɾɝ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðə peɪpɝz ɑn ɪz teɪbəl wɝ weɪd daʊn wɪð vɛɹiəs ɹɑks i hæd pɪkt ʌp, lɪt baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl flɪkɝɪŋ læmp.

Mat's tent rippled in the wind. His seat did look odd, the fine oak table sitting in a patch of hensfoot, Mat's chair beside it, a pitcher of mulled cider on the ground beside him. The papers on his table were weighed down with various rocks he had picked up, lit by a single flickering lamp.

hi ʃəd nɑɾ əv tə hæv stæks ə peɪpɝ. hi ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə sɪɾ ət wʌn ə ðoʊz faɪɝz ən sɪŋ "dæns wɪð dʒæk oʊ' ðə ʃædoʊz." hi kəd feɪnli meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz ə ðə sɔŋ fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ kæmpfaɪɝ.

He should not have to have stacks of paper. He should be able to sit at one of those fires and sing "Dance with Jak o' the Shadows." He could faintly make out the words of the song from a nearby campfire.

peɪpɝz. wɛl, hi hæɾ əɡɹid tə ɪleɪnz ɛmplɔɪmənt, ən ðəɹ wɝ peɪpɝz fəɹ ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ.

Papers. Well, he had agreed to Elayne's employment, and there were papers for that sort of thing.

ən peɪpɝz əbaʊt sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ðə dʒɹæɡən kɹuz. peɪpɝz əbaʊt səplaɪz, dɪsəplən ɹɪpɔɹts, ən ɔl kaɪnz ə nɑnsɛns. ən ə fju peɪpɝz i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə wɪɡəl aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹɔɪəl mædʒəsti, spaɪ ɹɪpɔɹts i hæd wɑntəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ. ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ðə sintʃæn.

And papers about setting up the dragon crews. Papers about supplies, discipline reports, and all kinds of nonsense. And a few papers he had been able to wiggle out of her royal majesty, spy reports he had wanted to look over. Reports on the Seanchan.

mʌtʃ ə ðə nuz wɑz nɑt nu tə hɪm; baɪ kɝɾəsi ʌv vɛɹɪnz ɡeɪtweɪ, mæt hæd tʃɹævəl tə keɪɛmlɪn mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən moʊst ɹumɝz. bʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd ɡeɪtweɪz ə hɝ oʊn, ən səm ə ðə nuz fɹəm tiɹ ən ɪljən wɑz fɹɛʃ. ðəɹ wɑz tɔk ə ðə nu sintʃæn ɛmpɹɛs. soʊ tuɑn ɹɪli hæd kɹaʊn hɝsɛlf, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ðə sintʃæn dɪd tə neɪm ə nu liɾɝ.

Much of the news was not new to him; by courtesy of Verin's gateway, Mat had traveled to Caemlyn more quickly than most rumors. But Elayne had gateways of her own, and some of the news from Tear and Illian was fresh. There was talk of the new Seanchan Empress. So Tuon really had crowned herself, or whatever it was the Seanchan did to name a new leader.

ðət meɪɾ ɪm smaɪl. laɪt, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɪn fɔɹ! ðeɪ pɹɑbli θɔt ðeɪ dɪd. bʌt ʃi wəd sɝpɹaɪz ðɛm, ʃʊɹ əz ðə skaɪ wɑz blu. ɔɹ, wɛl, ɪt hæd bɪn ɡɹeɪ leɪtli.

That made him smile. Light, but they did not know what they were in for! They probably thought they did. But she would surprise them, sure as the sky was blue. Or, well, it had been gray lately.

ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ tɔk ə si foʊk ɪn əlaɪəns wɪð ðə sintʃæn. mæt dɪsmɪs ðæt. ðə sintʃæn hæd kæptʃɝɾ ɪnʌf si foʊk vɛsəlz tə ɡɪv ðəɾ ɪmpɹɛʃən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə tʃɹuθ. hi faʊn səm peɪdʒəz wɪð nuz əbaʊt ɹænd, tu, moʊst ʌv ɪɾ ənspəsɪfɪk əɹ əntʃɹʌstwɝði.

There was also talk of Sea Folk in alliance with the Seanchan. Mat dismissed that. The Seanchan had captured enough Sea Folk vessels to give that impression, but it was not the truth. He found some pages with news about Rand, too, most of it unspecific or untrustworthy.

blæstəd kʌlɝz. ɹænd wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ən tɔkɪŋ wɪð səm pipəl ɪn ə tɛnt. pɝhæps i wɑz ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bi boʊθ ðəɹ ən faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, naʊ kəd hi? wʌn ɹumɝ sɛd ðət ɹænd hæd kɪl kwin taɪlɪn. wɪtʃ blʌɾi ɪɾiəts θɔt ðæt?

Blasted colors. Rand was sitting around and talking with some people in a tent. Perhaps he was in Arad Doman, but he could not be both there and fighting in the Borderlands, now could he? One rumor said that Rand had killed Queen Tylin. Which bloody idiots thought that?

hi tɝn oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ɹænd kwɪkli. hi heɪɾəd hævɪŋ tə bænɪʃ ðoʊz fleɪmɪŋ kʌlɝz oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əɡɛn. ət list ɹænd wɑz wɛɹɪŋ kloʊðz ðɪs taɪm.

He turned over the reports on Rand quickly. He hated having to banish those flaming colors over and over again. At least Rand was wearing clothes this time.

ðə læs peɪdʒ wɑz kjʊɹiəs. wʊlvz ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ɪnɔɹməs pæks, kɑŋɡɹəɡeɪɾɪŋ ɪn klɪɹɪŋz ən haʊlɪŋ ɪn kɔɹəs? ðə skaɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ ɹɛɾ ət naɪt? laɪvstɑk laɪnɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə filz, ɔl feɪsɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə nɔɹθ, wɑtʃɪŋ saɪlənli? ðə fʊtpɹɪns ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ɑɹmiz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə filz?

The last page was curious. Wolves running in enormous packs, congregating in clearings and howling in chorus? The skies shining red at night? Livestock lining up in the fields, all facing toward the north, watching silently? The footprints of Shadowspawn armies in the middle of fields?

ðiz θɪŋz smɛld ə sɪmpəl hɪɹseɪ, pæst ɑn fɹəm fɑɹmwaɪf tə fɑɹm-waɪf əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði ɪɹz ʌv ɪleɪnz spaɪz.

These things smelled of simple hearsay, passed on from farmwife to farm-wife until they reached the ears of Elayne's spies.

mæt lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə ʃit, ðən - wɪθaʊɾ ivən θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt-ɹilaɪzd i hæd pʊl vɛɹɪnz ɛnvəloʊp aʊɾ ə hɪz pɑkət. ðə stɪl-sild lɛɾɝ wɑz lʊkɪŋ wɔɹn ən dɝɾi, bʌɾ i hæd nɑɾ oʊpən ɪt. ɪt sim lk ðə moʊs dɪfəkəl θɪŋ i hæɾ ɛvɝ dʌn, ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ðætslæʃɝdʒ.

Mat looked over the sheet, then - without even thinking of it-realized he had pulled Verin's envelope out of his pocket. The still-sealed letter was looking worn and dirty, but he had not opened it. It seemed lke the most difficult thing he had ever done, resisting that;/urge.

"naʊ ðəɾ ɪz ə saɪɾ ə səm ɪɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi," ə wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd. mæt lʊkt ʌp tə si sɛɾəl stʃɹoʊlɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. ʃi wɔɹ ə bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs ðət leɪst oʊvɝ əɹ æmpəl bʊzəm. nɑt ðət mæt spɛn ɛni taɪm lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt.

"Now that is a sight of some irregularity," a woman's voice said. Mat looked up to see Setalle strolling toward him. She wore a brown dress that laced over her ample bosom. Not that Mat spent any time looking at it.

"ju laɪk maɪ dɛn?" mæt æskt. hi sɛt ði ɛnvəloʊp əsaɪd, ðən pʊt ðə læst ə ðə spaɪ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ə stæk, dʒʌs bɪsaɪɾ ə sɪɹiz ə skɛtʃəz hid bɪn duɪŋ ɑn səm nu kɹɔsboʊz, beɪst ɑn ðə wʌnz tælmɑnz hæd bɑt ðə peɪpɝz θɹɛɾənd tə bloʊ əweɪ. əz i hæd noʊ ɹɑk fəɹ ðɪs stæk, hi pʊld ɔf wʌn ə hɪz buts ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə tɑp.

"You like my den?" Mat asked. He set the envelope aside, then put the last of the spy reports on a stack, just beside a series of sketches he'd been doing on some new crossbows, based on the ones Talmanes had bought The papers threatened to blow away. As he had no rock for this stack, he pulled off one of his boots and set it on the top.

"jɔɹ dɛn?" sɛɾəl æskt, saʊndɪŋ əmjuzd.

"Your den?" Setalle asked, sounding amused.

"ʃʊɹ," mæt sɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ ðə bɑɾəm ə hɪz stɑkɪnɡd fʊt. "jul əv tə meɪk ən əpɔɪnmənt wɪð maɪ stuɝɾ ɪf jə wɑnə kʌm ɪn."

"Sure," Mat said, scratching the bottom of his stockinged foot. "You'll have to make an appointment with my steward if you want to come in."

"jɔɹ stuɝd?"

"Your steward?"

"ðə stʌmp ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ," mæt sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ. "nɑt ðə lɪɾəl wʌn, ðə bɪɡ wʌn wɪð mɔs ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑn ðə tɑp."

"The stump right over there," Mat said, nodding. "Not the little one, the big one with moss growing on the top."

ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

She raised an eyebrow.

"hiz kwaɪt ɡʊd," mæt sɛd. "hɑɹdli ɛvɝ lɛts ɛniwʌn ɪn aɪ doʊnt wɑnə si."

"He's quite good," Mat said. "Hardly ever lets anyone in I don't want to see."

"ju ɑɹ ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ kɹitʃɝ, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," sɛɾəl sɛd, siɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə lɑɹdʒɝ stʌmp. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz æftɝ ði ɛbu dɑɹ staɪl, wɪð ðə saɪd pɪn ʌp tə ɹɪvil pɛɾikoʊts kʌlɝfəl ɪnʌf tə skɛɹ əweɪ ə tɪŋkɝ.

"You are an interesting creature, Matrim Cauthon," Setalle said, seating herself on the larger stump. Her dress was after the Ebou Dar style, with the side pinned up to reveal petticoats colorful enough to scare away a Tinker.

"dɪd jə wɑn ɛniθɪŋ spəsɪfɪk?" mæt æskt. "ɔɹ dɪd jə dʒʌs dʒɹɑp baɪ soʊ ðət jə kəd sɪɾ ɑn maɪ stuɝdz hɛd?"

"Did you want anything specific?" Mat asked. "Or did you just drop by so that you could sit on my steward's head?"

"aɪ hɝd ðət jə vɪzəɾəd ðə pæləs əɡɛn tədeɪ. ɪz ɪt tʃɹu ðət jə noʊ ðə kwin?"

"I heard that you visited the palace again today. Is it true that you know the Queen?"

mæt ʃɹʌɡd. "ɪleɪnz ə naɪs ɪnʌf ɡɝl. pɹɪɾi θɪŋ, ðæts fəɹ sɝɾən."

Mat shrugged. "Elayne's a nice enough girl. Pretty thing, that's for certain."

"ju doʊnt ʃɑk mi ɛnimɔɹ, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," sɛɾəl noʊɾəd. "aɪv ɹilaɪz ðət ðə θɪŋz jə seɪ ɑɹ ɔfən ɪntɛndəd tə də ðæt."

"You don't shock me anymore, Matrim Cauthon," Setalle noted. "I've realized that the things you say are often intended to do that."

ðeɪ wɝ? "aɪ seɪ wʌɾ aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən. waɪ dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ tə jə ɪf aɪ noʊ ðə kwin?"

They were? "I say what I'm thinking, Mistress Anan. Why does it matter to you if I know the Queen?"

"mɪɹli ənʌðɝ pis ə ðə pʌzəl ðət jə ɹɛpɹəzɛnt," sɛɾəl sɛd. "aɪ ɹəsivd ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm dʒoʊlin tədeɪ."

"Merely another piece of the puzzle that you represent," Setalle said. "I received a letter from Joline today."

"wʌt dɪd ʃi wɑn fɹəm ju?"

"What did she want from you?"

"ʃi dɪdn æsk fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ. ʃi mɪɹli wɑntəd tə sɛnd wɝd ðət ðeɪ hæɾ ɝaɪv seɪfli ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"She didn't ask for anything. She merely wanted to send word that they had arrived safely in Tar Valon."

"ju mʌst əv ɹɛɾ ɪt ɹɔŋ."

"You must have read it wrong."

sɛɾəl ɡeɪv ɪm ə tʃaɪɾɪŋ stɛɹ. "dʒoʊlin sədaɪ ɹɪspɛks ju, mæstɝ kɔθən. ʃi ɔfən spoʊk haɪli ʌv ju, ən ðə weɪ ðət jə ɹɛskjud nɑɾ oʊnli hɝ, bʌt ði ʌðɝ tu. ʃi æskt æftɝ jə ɪn ðə lɛɾɝ."

Setalle gave him a chiding stare. "Joline Sedai respects you, Master Cauthon. She often spoke highly of you, and the way that you rescued not only her, but the other two. She asked after you in the letter."

mæt blɪŋkt. "ɹɪli? ʃi sɛd θɪŋz laɪk ðæt?"

Mat blinked. "Really? She said things like that?"

sɛɾəl nɑɾəd.

Setalle nodded.

"bɝn mi," hi sɛd. "ɔlmoʊs meɪks mi fil bæd fəɹ peɪntɪŋ əɹ maʊθ blu. bʌt jə wʊdn əv noʊn ʃi θɔt ðət weɪ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ ʃi tʃɹiɾəd mi."

"Burn me," he said. "Almost makes me feel bad for painting her mouth blue. But you wouldn't have known she thought that way, considering how she treated me."

"spikɪŋ sətʃ θɪŋz tə ə mæn ɪnfleɪts ɪz əpɪnjən ə hɪmsɛlf. wʌn wəd θɪŋk ðət ðə weɪ ʃi tʃɹiɾəd jə wʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf."

"Speaking such things to a man inflates his opinion of himself. One would think that the way she treated you would have been enough."

"ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ," mæt mʌɾɝd. "ʃi tʃɹits ɛvɹiwʌn laɪk ðəɹ mʌd tə bi skɹeɪpt ɔf əɹ buts."

"She's Aes Sedai," Mat muttered. "She treats everyone like they're mud to be scraped off her boots."

sɛɾəl ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm. ʃi hæɾ ə steɪtli weɪ əbaʊt hɝ, pɑɹt ɡɹændmʌðɝ, pɑɹt kɔɹt leɪɾi, pɑɹt noʊ- nɑnsɛns ɪnkipɝ.

Setalle glared at him. She had a stately way about her, part grandmother, part court lady, part no- nonsense innkeeper.

"sɑɹi," hi sɛd. "sʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹən əz bæɾ əz ʌðɝz. aɪ dɪdn min tə ɪnsʌl ju."

"Sorry," he said. "Some Aes Sedai aren't as bad as others. I didn't mean to insult you."

"aɪl teɪk ðət fəɹ ə kɑmpləmənt," sɛɾəl sɛd. "ðoʊ aɪm nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I'll take that for a compliment," Setalle said. "Though I'm not Aes Sedai."

mæt ʃɹʌɡd, faɪndɪŋ ə naɪs smɔl ɹɑk əɾ ɪz fit. hi juzd ɪt tə ɹipleɪs ɪz buɾ ətɑp ðə stæk ə peɪpɝ. ðə ɹeɪnz ə ðə læs fju deɪz hæd pæst, livɪŋ ə kɹɪsp fɹɛʃnəs tə ði ɛɹ. "aɪ noʊ jə sɛɾ ɪt dɪdn hɝt," mæt sɛd. "bʌt . . . wʌt dʌz ɪt fil laɪk? ðə θɪŋ jə lɔst?"

Mat shrugged, finding a nice small rock at his feet. He used it to replace his boot atop the stack of paper. The rains of the last few days had passed, leaving a crisp freshness to the air. "I know you said it didn't hurt," Mat said. "But . . . what does it feel like? The thing you lost?"

ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə moʊs dɪlaɪtfəl fud jə ɛndʒɔɪ, mæstɝ kɔθən? ðə wʌn θɪŋ ðət jə wəɾ iɾ əbʌv ɔl ʌðɝz?"

She pursed her lips. "What is the most delightful food you enjoy, Master Cauthon? The one thing that you would eat above all others?"

"mɑz swit paɪz," mæt sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli.

"Ma's sweet pies," Mat said immediately.

"wɛl, ɪts laɪk ðæt," sɛɾəl sɛd. "noʊɪŋ ðət jə juz tə bi eɪbəl tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðoʊz paɪz ɛvɹi deɪ, bʌt naʊ ðeɪv bɪn dɪnaɪd ju. jəɹ fɹɛnz, ðeɪ kən əv əz mɛni ʌv ðoʊz paɪz əz ðeɪ wɑnt. jə ɛnvi ðɛm, ən jə hɝt, bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm jəɹ hæpi. ət list sʌmwʌn kən ɛndʒɔɪ wʌt jə kænɑt."

"Well, it is like that," Setalle said. "Knowing that you used to be able to enjoy those pies every day, but now they have been denied you. Your friends, they can have as many of those pies as they want. You envy them, and you hurt, but at the same time you're happy. At least someone can enjoy what you cannot."

mæt nɑɾəd sloʊli.

Mat nodded slowly.

"waɪ ɪz ɪt ðət jə heɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ soʊ, mæstɝ kɔθən?" sɛɾəl æskt.

"Why is it that you hate Aes Sedai so, Master Cauthon?" Setalle asked.

"aɪ doʊn heɪt ðɛm," mæt sɛd. "bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt. bʌt səmtaɪmz, ə mæn kæn sim tə də tu θɪŋz wɪθaʊt wɪmən wɑntɪŋ ɪm tə də wʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz ə dɪfɹənt weɪ ən ɪɡnɔɹ ði ʌðɝ wʌn kəmplitli."

"I don't hate them," Mat said. "Burn me, but I don't. But sometimes, a man can't seem to do two things without women wanting him to do one of those things a different way and ignore the other one completely."

"ju ɑɹən fɔɹs tə teɪk ðɛɹ ædvaɪs, ən aɪ wɔɹən ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə taɪm, jə ɪvɛntʃəwəli ədmɪɾ ɪts ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs."

"You aren't forced to take their advice, and I warrant that much of the time, you eventually admit it is good advice."

mæt ʃɹʌɡd. "səmtaɪmz, ə mæn dʒʌs laɪks tə də wʌɾ i wɑns wɪθaʊt sʌmwʌn tɛlɪŋ ɪm wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð ɪɾ ən wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð hɪm. ðæts ɔl."

Mat shrugged. "Sometimes, a man just likes to do what he wants without someone telling him what's wrong with it and what's wrong with him. That's all."

"æn ɪts nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð jəɹ . . . pəkjuljɝ vjuz ə noʊbəlz? moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ noʊbəlwɪmən, æftɝ ɔl."

"And it has nothing to do with your . . . peculiar views of nobles? Most Aes Sedai act as if they were noblewomen, after all."

"aɪ hæv nʌθɪŋ əɡɛns noʊbəlz," mæt sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ɪz koʊt. "aɪ dʒʌs doʊn fænsi biɪŋ wʌn maɪsɛlf."

"I have nothing against nobles," Mat said, straightening his coat. "I just don't fancy being one myself."

"waɪ ɪz ðæt, ðɛn?"

"Why is that, then?"

mæt sæt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. waɪ wɑz ɪt? faɪnəli, hi lʊk daʊn əɾ ɪz fʊt ðən ɹipleɪst ɪz but.

Mat sat for a moment. Why was it? Finally, he looked down at his foot then replaced his boot.

"ɪts buts."

"It's boots."

"buts?" sɛɾəl lʊkt kənfjuzd.

"Boots?" Setalle looked confused.

"buts," mæt sɛd wɪð ə nɑd, taɪɪŋ ɪz leɪsəz. "ɪts ɔl əbaʊt ðə buts."

"Boots," Mat said with a nod, tying his laces. "It's all about the boots."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ju si," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ðə leɪsəz taɪt, "ə lɑɾ ə mɛn doʊn əv tə wɝi mʌtʃ əbaʊt wʌt buts tə wɛɹ. ðəɹ ðə pʊɹɪst ə foʊks. ɪf jə æsk wʌn ə ðɛm 'wʌt buts ɑɹ jə gɑnə wɛɹ tədeɪ, mɑp?' ðɛɹ ænsɝ ɪz izi. 'wɛl, mæt. aɪ oʊnli hæv wʌn pɛɹ, soʊ aɪ ɡɛs aɪm ɡɑnə wɛɹ ðət pɛɹ.'"

"You see," Mat said, pulling the laces tight, "a lot of men don't have to worry much about what boots to wear. They're the poorest of folks. If you ask one of them 'What boots are you going to wear today, Mop?' their answer is easy. 'Well, Mat. I only have one pair, so I guess I'm gonna wear that pair.'"

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ɔɹ, aɪ ɡɛs ðeɪ wʊdn seɪ ðət tə ju, sɛɾəl, sɪns jəɹ nɑt mi ən ɔl. ðeɪ wʊdn kɔl jə mæt, jə ʌndɝstænd."

Mat hesitated. "Or, I guess they wouldn't say that to you, Setalle, since you're not me and all. They wouldn't call you Mat, you understand."

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ əmjuzd.

"I understand," she said, sounding amused.

"ɛniweɪ, fəɹ pipəl ðəɾ əv ə lɪɾəl kɔɪn, ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv wɪtʃ buts tə wɛɹ ɪz hɑɹɾɝ. jə si, ævɝɪdʒ mɛn, mɛn laɪk mi. . . ." hi aɪd hɝ. "æn ɪm ən ævɝɪdʒ mæn, maɪn ju."

"Anyway, for people that have a little coin, the question of which boots to wear is harder. You see, average men, men like me. . . ." He eyed her. "And I'm an average man, mind you."

"ʌv kɔɹs jə ɑɹ."

"Of course you are."

"blʌɾi ɹaɪɾ aɪ æm," mæt sɛd, fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ɪz leɪsəz ən sɪɾɪŋ ʌp. "æn ævɝɪdʒ mæn maɪɾ əv θɹi pɛɹz ə buts. jəɹ θɝd bɛs pɛɹ ə buts, ðoʊz ɑɹ ðə buts jə wɛɹ wən jəɹ wɝkɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ ənplɛzənt. ðeɪ maɪt ɹʌb æftɝ ə fju peɪsɪz, ən ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ə fju hoʊlz, bʌt ðəɹ ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf tə kip jəɹ fʊɾɪŋ. jə doʊn maɪn mʌkɪŋ əm ʌp ɪn ðə filz əɹ ðə bɑɹn."

"Bloody right I am," Mat said, finishing with his laces and sitting up. "An average man might have three pairs of boots. Your third best pair of boots, those are the boots you wear when you're working at something unpleasant. They might rub after a few paces, and they might have a few holes, but they're good enough to keep your footing. You don't mind mucking them up in the fields or the barn."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," sɛɾəl sɛd.

"All right," Setalle said.

"ðɛn juv jəɹ sɛkən bɛs pɛɹ ə buts," mæt sɛd. "ðoʊz ɑɹ jəɹ deɪ-tə-deɪ buts. jə wɛɹ ðoʊz ɪf jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ tə dɪnɝ ət ðə neɪbɝz. ɔɹ, ɪn maɪ keɪs, jə wɛɹ ðoʊz ɪf jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə bæɾəl. ðəɹ naɪs buts, ɡɪv jə ɡʊd fʊɾɪŋ, ən jə doʊn maɪn biɪŋ sin ɪn əm əɹ ɛniθɪŋ."

"Then you have your second best pair of boots," Mat said. "Those are your day-to-day boots. You wear those if you are going over to dinner at the neighbors. Or, in my case, you wear those if you're going to battle. They're nice boots, give you good footing, and you don't mind being seen in them or anything."

"æn jəɹ bɛs pɛɹ ə buts?" sɛɾəl æskt. "ju wɛɹ ðoʊz tə soʊʃəl ɪvɛns, laɪk ə bɔl əɹ daɪnɪŋ wɪð ə loʊkəl dɪɡnətɛɹi?"

"And your best pair of boots?" Setalle asked. "You wear those to social events, like a ball or dining with a local dignitary?"

"bɔlz? dɪɡnətɛɹiz? blʌɾi æʃəz, wʊmən. aɪ θɔt jə wɝ ən ɪn-kipɝ."

"Balls? Dignitaries? Bloody ashes, woman. I thought you were an inn-keeper."

sɛɾəl blʌʃt feɪnli.

Setalle blushed faintly.

"wɝ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɛni bɔlz," mæt sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪf wi hæd tə, aɪ səspɛkt wid wɛɹ əɹ sɛkən bɛs pɛɹ ə buts. ɪf ðəɹ ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ oʊld leɪɾi hɛmbɹu nɛks dɔɹ, ðən ðəɹ blʌɾi wɛl ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ stɛpɪŋ ɑn ðə toʊz ʌv ɛni wʊmən ful ɪnʌf tə dæns wɪð ʌs."

"We're not going to any balls," Mat said. "But if we had to, I suspect we'd wear our second best pair of boots. If they're good enough for visiting old lady Hembrew next door, then they're bloody well good enough for stepping on the toes of any woman fool enough to dance with us."

"ðɛn wʌɾ ɑɹ ðə bɛs buts fɔɹ?"

"Then what are the best boots for?"

"wɔkɪŋ," mæt sɛd. "ɛni fɑɹmɝ noʊz ðə vælju ʌv ɡʊd buts wən jə ɡoʊ wɔkɪŋ ə dɪstəns."

"Walking," Mat said. "Any farmer knows the value of good boots when you go walking a distance."

sɛɾəl lʊk θɔtfəl. "ɔl ɹaɪt. bʌt wʌt dʌz ðɪs əv tə də wɪð biɪŋ ə noʊbəlmən?"

Setalle looked thoughtful. "All right. But what does this have to do with being a nobleman?"

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ," mæt sɛd. "doʊn jə si? ɪf jəɹ ən ævɝɪdʒ fɛloʊ, jə noʊ ɪɡzækli wən tə juz jəɹ buts. ə mæn kən kip tʃɹæk ə θɹi pɛɹz ə buts. laɪf ɪz sɪmpəl wən juv θɹi pɛɹz ə buts. bʌt noʊbəlmən . . . tælmɑnz kleɪmz hiz fɔɹɾi dɪfɹən pɛɹz ə buts ət hoʊm. fɔɹɾi pɛɹz, kən jə ɪmædʒən ðæt?"

"Everything," Mat said. "Don't you see? If you're an average fellow, you know exactly when to use your boots. A man can keep track of three pairs of boots. Life is simple when you have three pairs of boots. But noblemen . . . Talmanes claims he has forty different pairs of boots at home. Forty pairs, can you imagine that?"

ʃi smaɪld ɪn əmjuzmənt.

She smiled in amusement.

"fɔɹɾi pɛɹz," mæt ɹɪpiɾɪd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "fɔɹɾi blʌɾi pɛɹz. ænd, ðeɪ ɑɹən ɔl ðə seɪm kaɪndə buts iðɝ. ðəɹ ɪz ə pɛɹ fəɹ itʃ aʊtfɪt, ən ə dʌzən pɛɹz ɪn dɪfɹən staɪlz ðət wɪl mætʃ ɛni nʌmbɝ ə hæf jəɹ aʊtfɪts. juv buts fəɹ kɪŋz, buts fəɹ haɪ lɔɹdz, ən buts fəɹ nɔɹməl pipəl. juv buts fəɹ wɪntɝ ən buts fəɹ sʌmɝ, buts fəɹ ɹeɪni deɪz ən buts fəɹ dʒɹaɪ deɪz. juv blʌɾi ʃuz ðət jə wɛɹ oʊnli wən jəɹ wɔkɪŋ tə ðə beɪðɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ.

"Forty pairs," Mat repeated, shaking his head. "Forty bloody pairs. And, they aren't all the same kind of boots either. There is a pair for each outfit, and a dozen pairs in different styles that will match any number of half your outfits. You have boots for kings, boots for high lords, and boots for normal people. You have boots for winter and boots for summer, boots for rainy days and boots for dry days. You have bloody shoes that you wear only when you're walking to the bathing chamber.

ləpɪn juz tə kəmpleɪn ðəɾ aɪ dɪdn əv ə pɛɹ tə wɛɹ tə ðə pɹɪvi ət naɪt!"

Lopin used to complain that I didn't have a pair to wear to the privy at night!"

"aɪ si. ... soʊ jəɹ juzɪŋ buts əz ə mɛɾəfɔɹ fəɹ ði oʊnəs ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ən dɪsɪʒən pleɪst əpɑn ði ɛɹəstɑkɹəsi əz ðeɪ əsum liɾɝʃɪp ə kɑmplɛks pəlɪɾəkəl ən soʊʃəl pəzɪʃənz."

"I see. ... So you're using boots as a metaphor for the onus of responsibility and decision placed upon the aristocracy as they assume leadership of complex political and social positions."

"mɛɾəfɔɹ fɔɹ. . . ." mæt skaʊld. "blʌɾi æʃəz, wʊmən. ðɪs ɪzən ə mɛɾəfɔɹ fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ! ɪts dʒʌs buts"

"Metaphor for. . . ." Mat scowled. "Bloody ashes, woman. This isn't a metaphor for anything! It's just boots"

sɛɾəl ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "jɔɹ ən ʌnkənvɛnʃənəli waɪz mæn, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən."

Setalle shook her head. "You're an unconventionally wise man, Matrim Cauthon."

"aɪ tʃɹaɪ maɪ bɛst," hi noʊɾəd, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə pɪtʃɝ ə mʌl saɪɾɝ. "tə bi ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl, aɪ min."

"I try my best," he noted, reaching for the pitcher of mulled cider. "To be unconventional, I mean."

hi pɔɹɾ ə kʌp ən lɪftəɾ ɪɾ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. ʃi æksɛptɪd ɡɹeɪʃəsli ən dʒɹæŋk, ðən stʊd. "aɪ wɪl liv jə tə jəɹ oʊn əmjuzməns, ðɛn, mæstɝ kɔθən. bʌɾ ɪf juv meɪɾ ɛni pɹɑɡɹɛs ɑn ðət ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ mi. . . ."

He poured a cup and lifted it in her direction. She accepted graciously and drank, then stood. "I will leave you to your own amusements, then, Master Cauthon. But if you have made any progress on that gateway for me. . . ."

"ɪleɪn sɛd ʃi wəɾ əv wʌn fəɹ jə sun. ɪn ə deɪ əɹ tu. wʌns aɪm bæk fɹəm ði ɛɹən aɪ hæv tə ɹʌn wɪð θɔɹn ən noʊl, əl si ɪt dʌn."

"Elayne said she would have one for you soon. In a day or two. Once I'm back from the errand I have to run with Thorn and Noal, I'll see it done."

ʃi nɑɾəd ɪn ʌndɝstændɪŋ. ɪf i dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðət "ɛɹənd," ʃi wəd si tə oʊlvɝ. ʃi tɝn tə liv. mæt weɪɾəd əntɪl ʃi wɑz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ə slɝp ə ðə saɪɾɝ stʃɹeɪt fɹəm ðə pɪtʃɝ. hi hæd bɪn duɪŋ ðəɾ ɔl ivnɪŋ, bʌɾ i fɪɡjɝd ʃi wəd pɹɑbli ɹæðɝ nɑt noʊ. ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ wɪmən wɝ bɛɾɝ ɔf nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt.

She nodded in understanding. If he did not return from that "errand," she would see to Olver. She turned to leave. Mat waited until she was gone before taking a slurp of the cider straight from the pitcher. He had been doing that all evening, but he figured she would probably rather not know. It was the sort of thing women were better off not thinking about.

hi tɝn bæk tə hɪz ɹɪpɔɹts, bʌt sun faʊn ɪz maɪnd wɑndɝɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ, ən ðoʊz blʌɾi sneɪks ən fɑksəz. bɝdʒɪts kɑm-mɛns hæd bɪn ɛnlaɪɾənɪŋ, bʌt nɑt pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ. tu mʌnθs? tu blʌɾi mʌnθs spɛnt wɑndɝɪŋ ðoʊz hɔlweɪz? ðət wɑz ə maɪɾi, stimɪŋ boʊl ʌv wɝi, sɝvd ʌp laɪk æftɝnun slɑp. bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi hæd teɪkən faɪɝ, mjuzɪk, ən aɪɝn. bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹulz wɑz nɑt soʊ ɝɪdʒənəl ən aɪdiə.

He turned back to his reports, but soon found his mind wandering to the Tower of Ghenjei, and those bloody snakes and foxes. Birgitte's com-ments had been enlightening, but not particularly encouraging. Two months? Two bloody months spent wandering those hallways? That was a mighty, steaming bowl of worry, served up like afternoon slop. Beyond that, she had taken fire, music, and iron. Breaking the rules was not so original an idea.

hi wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd. laɪkli, ðə deɪ ðə laɪt meɪd ðə vɛɹi fɝs mæn, ən ðət mæn hæd meɪd ðə fɝst ɹul, sʌmwʌn ɛls hæd θɔt tə bɹeɪk ɪt. pipəl laɪk ɪleɪn meɪɾ ʌp ɹulz tə sut ðɛm. pipəl laɪk mæt faʊnd weɪz tə ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn ðə stupəd ɹulz.

He was not surprised. Likely, the day the Light made the very first man, and that man had made the first rule, someone else had thought to break it. People like Elayne made up rules to suit them. People like Mat found ways to get around the stupid rules.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, bɝdʒɪt - wʌn ə ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi hɪɹoʊz ə ðə hɔɹn -  hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə dɪfit ði æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn. ðət wɑz dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ.

Unfortunately, Birgitte - one of the legendary Heroes of the Horn -  had not been able to defeat the Aelfinn and Eelfinn. That was disconcerting.

wɛl, mæt hæd sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hæd nɑt hæd. hɪz lʌk. hi sæt θɔtfəli, linɪŋ bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ.

Well, Mat had something she had not had. His luck. He sat thoughtfully, leaning back in his chair.

wʌn ə hɪz soʊlʒɝz pæs baɪ. klɪntɑk səluɾəd; ðə ɹɛdɑɹm tʃɛkt ɑn mæt ɛvɹi hæf-aʊɝ. ðeɪ stɪl hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən oʊvɝ ðə ʃeɪm ə lɛɾɪŋ ðə ɡboʊləm snik ɪndə kæmp.

One of his soldiers passed by. Clintock saluted; the Redarm checked on Mat every half-hour. They still had not gotten over the shame of letting the gbolam sneak into camp.

hi pɪkt ʌp vɛɹɪnz lɛɾɝ əɡɛn, filɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə wɔɹn kɔɹnɝz, ðə smʌdʒɪz ə dɝɾ ɑn ðə wʌns-waɪt peɪpɝ. hi tæpt ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə wʊd.

He picked up Verin's letter again, feeling it over in his fingers. The worn corners, the smudges of dirt on the once-white paper. He tapped it against the wood.

ðən i tɔst ɪɾ ɑntu ðə dɛsk. noʊ. noʊ, hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə oʊpən ɪt, ivən wən i ɡɑt bæk. ðət wɑz ðæt. hi wəd nɛvɝ noʊ wʌt wɑz ɪn ɪt, ən i blʌɾi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ.

Then he tossed it onto the desk. No. No, he was not going to open it, even when he got back. That was that. He would never know what was in it, and he bloody did not care.

hi stʊɾ ʌp ən wɛn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ θɔɹn ən noʊl. təmɑɹoʊ, ðeɪ wəd liv fəɹ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ.

He stood up and went looking for Thorn and Noal. Tomorrow, they would leave for the Tower of Ghenjei.


tʃæptɝ fɪftiθɹi


CHAPTER 53

pɛvɑɹə kɛpt əɹ tʌŋ əz ʃi wɔk θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ ə ðə blæk taʊɝ wɪð dʒəvɪnʒɹə ænd


Pevara kept her tongue as she walked through the village of the Black Tower with Javindhra and

mæzɹim teɪm. ðəɹ wɑz æktɪvəɾi ɔl θɹu ðə pleɪs. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz æktɪvəɾi ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ. soʊlʒɝz fɛlɪŋ tʃɹiz nɪɹbaɪ; dɛɾəkeɪtəd stʃɹɪpɪŋ ðə bɑɹk əweɪ, ðən slaɪsɪŋ ðə lɔɡz ɪndə lʌmbɝ wɪð foʊkəs dʒɛts ʌv ɛɹ. sɔdʌs koʊɾəd ðə pæθ; wɪð ə tʃɪl, pɛvɑɹə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə stæk ə bɔɹdz nɪɹbaɪ hæd pɹɑbli bɪn kʌt baɪ æʃəmən.

Mazrim Taim. There was activity all through the place. There was always activity in the Black Tower. Soldiers felling trees nearby; Dedicated stripping the bark away, then slicing the logs into lumber with focused jets of Air. Sawdust coated the path; with a chill, Pevara realized that the stack of boards nearby had probably been cut by Asha'man.

laɪt! ʃid noʊn wʌt ʃid faɪn hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ tə feɪs ðən ʃiɾ əsumd ɪt wəd bi.

Light! She'd known what she'd find here. It was much harder to face than she'd assumed it would be.

"æn jə si," teɪm sɛd, wɔkɪŋ wɪð wʌn hæn foʊldəd - fɪŋɡɝz meɪkɪŋ ə fɪst - bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk.

"And you see," Taim said, walking with one hand folded - fingers making a fist - behind his back.

wɪð ɪz ʌðɝ hænd, hi pɔɪntəd təwɔɹɾ ə dɪstənt, pɑɹt-fɪnɪʃt wɔl ə blæk stoʊn. "ɡɑɹd poʊsts speɪst ət fɪfti-fʊɾ ɪntɝvəlz. itʃ wɪð tu æʃəmən ətɑp ðɛm." hi smaɪld ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən. "ðɪs pleɪs wɪl bi ɪmpɹɛɡnəbəl."

With his other hand, he pointed toward a distant, part-finished wall of black stone. "Guard posts spaced at fifty-foot intervals. Each with two Asha'man atop them." He smiled in satisfaction. "This place will be impregnable."

"jɛs ɪndid," dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɛd. "ɪmpɹɛsɪv." hɝ toʊn wɑz flæɾ ən ənɪntʃɹəstəd. "bʌt ði aɪɾəm aɪ wɪʃt tə spik wɪð jə əbaʊt. ɪf wi kəd tʃuz mɛn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən pɪn tə - "

"Yes indeed," Javindhra said. "Impressive." Her tone was flat and uninterested. "But the item I wished to speak with you about. If we could choose men with the Dragon pin to - "

"ðɪs əɡɛn?" teɪm sɛd. hi hæd faɪɝ ɪn ɪz aɪz, ðɪs mæzɹim teɪm. ə tɔl, blæk-hɛɹd mæn wɪð haɪ, sɑldəiən tʃikboʊnz. hi smaɪld. əɹ ðə kloʊsəst i keɪm tə sətʃ ən ɪkspɹɛʃən - ə hæf-smaɪl ðət dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ ɪz aɪz. ɪt lʊkt . . . pɹɛɾətɔɹi. "aɪ hæv meɪd maɪ wɪl noʊn. ən jɛt jə kəntɪnju tə pʊʃ. noʊ. soʊlʒɝz ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd oʊnli."

"This again?" Taim said. He had fire in his eyes, this Mazrim Taim. A tall, black-haired man with high, Saldaean cheekbones. He smiled. Or the closest he came to such an expression - a half-smile that did not reach his eyes. It looked . . . predatory. "I have made my will known. And yet you continue to push. No. Soldiers and Dedicated only."

"æz jə dɪmænd," dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɛd. "wi wɪl kəntɪnju əɹ kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən."

"As you demand," Javindhra said. "We will continue our consideration."

"wiks pæs," teɪm ɹɪplaɪd, "æn stɪl jə kənsɪɾɝ? wɛl, fɑɹ bi ɪt fɹəm mi tə kwɛstʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ kɛɹ nɑt wʌt jə du. bʌt ðə wɪmən aʊtsaɪd maɪ ɡeɪts kleɪm tə bi fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz wɛl. dʒju nɑt wɪʃ mi tə ɪnvaɪɾ əm ɪn tə mit wɪð ju?"

"Weeks pass," Taim replied, "and still you consider? Well, far be it from me to question Aes Sedai. I care not what you do. But the women outside my gates claim to be from the White Tower as well. Do you not wish me to invite them in to meet with you?"

pɛvɑɹə fɛlt ə tʃɪl. hi ɔlweɪz sim tə noʊ tu mʌtʃ, ən hɪn ðəɾ i nu tu mʌtʃ, əbaʊɾ ɪntɝnəl waɪt taʊɝ pɑlətɪks.

Pevara felt a chill. He always seemed to know too much, and hint that he knew too much, about internal White Tower politics.

"ðæt woʊn bi niɾəd," dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɛd koʊldli.

"That won't be needed," Javindhra said coldly.

"æz jə wɪʃ," hi sɛd. "ju ʃəd meɪk jəɹ tʃɔɪsəz sun. ðeɪ ɡɹoʊ ɪmpeɪʃənt, ən ælθɹ əz ɡɪvən əm pɝmɪʃən tə bɑn maɪ mɛn. ðəl nɑt sʌfɝ maɪ stɔlɪŋ fɝɛvɝ."

"As you wish," he said. "You should make your choices soon. They grow impatient, and al'Thor has given them permission to bond my men. They will not suffer my stalling forever."

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛbəlz. jə nid peɪ ðɛm noʊ hiɾ əɾ ɔl."

"They are rebels. You need pay them no heed at all."

"ɹɛbəlz," teɪm sɛd, "wɪð ə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ fɔɹs ðən ju. wʌt dʒju hæv? sɪks wɪmən? fɹəm ðə weɪ jə tɔk, jə sim tə ɪntɛn tə bɑn ði ɪntaɪɝɾi ʌv ðə blæk taʊɝ!"

"Rebels," Taim said, "with a much larger force than you. What do you have? Six women? From the way you talk, you seem to intend to bond the entirety of the Black Tower!"

"pɝhæps wi maɪt." pɛvɑɹə spoʊk kɑmli. "noʊ lɪmət wɑz pleɪst əpɑn ʌs."

"Perhaps we might." Pevara spoke calmly. "No limit was placed upon us."

teɪm ɡlænst ət hɝ, ən ʃi hæd ðə dɪstɪŋk filɪŋ ʃi wɑz biɪŋ ɪnspɛktɪd baɪ ə wʊlf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃid meɪk ə ɡʊd mil. ʃi ʃʌv ðət filɪŋ əsaɪd. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, noʊ izi mit. stɪl, ʃi kʊdn hɛlp ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli sɪks. ɪnsaɪɾ ə kæmp fɪld wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl.

Taim glanced at her, and she had the distinct feeling she was being inspected by a wolf considering whether she'd make a good meal. She shoved that feeling aside. She was Aes Sedai, no easy meat. Still, she couldn't help remembering that they were only six. Inside a camp filled with hundreds of men who could channel.

"aɪ wʌns sɔ ə skaɪfɪʃɝ daɪɪŋ ɑn ðə sɪɾi dɑks ʌv ɪljən," teɪm sɛd. "ðə bɝd wɑz tʃoʊkɪŋ, hævɪŋ tʃɹaɪd tə swɑloʊ tu fɪʃ ət wʌns."

"I once saw a skyfisher dying on the city docks of Illian," Taim said. "The bird was choking, having tried to swallow two fish at once."

"dɪd jə hɛlp ðə sɑɹi θɪŋ?" dʒəvɪnʒɹə æskt.

"Did you help the sorry thing?" Javindhra asked.

"fulz wɪl ɔlweɪz tʃoʊk ðɛmsɛlvz wən ðeɪ ɡɹæsp fəɹ tu mʌtʃ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," teɪm sɛd.

"Fools will always choke themselves when they grasp for too much, Aes Sedai," Taim said.

"wʌt mæɾɝz ðət tə mi? aɪ hæɾ ə faɪn mil ʌv ɪt ðət naɪt. ðə flɛʃ ə ðə bɝd, ən ə ðə fɪʃ. aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ. bʌt bi wɔɹnd, naʊ ðəɾ aɪ hæv ə dɪfɛnsəbəl pɝɪməɾɝ, jə mʌst ɡɪmi wɔɹnɪŋ ɪf jə wɪʃ tə pæs aʊtsaɪd."

"What matters that to me? I had a fine meal of it that night. The flesh of the bird, and of the fish. I must go. But be warned, now that I have a defensible perimeter, you must give me warning if you wish to pass outside."

"ju min tə kip kʌmɪŋz ən ɡoʊɪŋz ðət taɪt?" pɛvɑɹə æskt.

"You mean to keep comings and goings that tight?" Pevara asked.

"ðə wɝl bɪkʌmz ə deɪnʒɝəs pleɪs," teɪm sɛd smuðli. "aɪ mʌs θɪŋk ə ðə nidz ə maɪ mɛn."

"The world becomes a dangerous place," Taim said smoothly. "I must think of the needs of my men."

pɛvɑɹə hæd noʊɾəst haʊ hi sɔ tə ðə "nidz" ʌv ɪz mɛn. ə ɡɹup ə jʌŋ soʊlʒɝz pæs baɪ, səluɾɪŋ teɪm. tu bɔɹ bɹuz fitʃɝz, wʌn wɪð ən aɪ swoʊlən ʃʌt. æʃəmən wɝ biɾən bɹuɾəli fəɹ meɪkɪŋ mɪsteɪks ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ðən fɔɹbɪɾən hilɪŋ.

Pevara had noticed how he saw to the "needs" of his men. A group of young soldiers passed by, saluting Taim. Two bore bruised features, one with an eye swollen shut. Asha'man were beaten brutally for making mistakes in their training, then forbidden Healing.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ nɛvɝ tʌtʃt. ɪn fækt, ðə dɛfɝəns ðeɪ wɝ ʃoʊn bɔɹɾɝd ɑn mɑkɝi.

The Aes Sedai were never touched. In fact, the deference they were shown bordered on mockery.

teɪm nɑɾəd, ðən stɔkt ɔf, miɾɪŋ ʌp wɪð tu ʌv ɪz æʃəmən u weɪɾəd nɪɹbaɪ, bɪsaɪd ðə smɪθi. ðeɪ ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡæn spikɪŋ ɪn hʌʃt toʊnz.

Taim nodded, then stalked off, meeting up with two of his Asha'man who waited nearby, beside the smithy. They immediately began speaking in hushed tones.

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs," pɛvɑɹə sɛɾ əz sun əz ðə mɛn wɝ əweɪ. pɝhæps ʃi sɛɾ ɪt tu kwɪkli, bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ əɹ wɝiz, bʌt ðɪs pleɪs hæɾ əɹ ɑn ɛdʒ. "ðɪs kəɾ izəli tɝn tə dɪzæstɝ. aɪm bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ðət wi ʃəd də əz aɪ ɝɪdʒənəli steɪɾəd - bɑn ə fju dɛɾəkeɪtəd itʃ ən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əɹ tæsk wɑz nɛvɝ tə lɑk daʊn ði ɪntaɪɝ blæk taʊɝ, bʌt tə ɡeɪn æksɛs tə æʃəmən ən lɝn əbaʊt ðɛm."

"I don't like this," Pevara said as soon as the men were away. Perhaps she said it too quickly, betraying her worries, but this place had her on edge. "This could easily turn to disaster. I'm beginning to think that we should do as I originally stated - bond a few Dedicated each and return to the White Tower. Our task was never to lock down the entire Black Tower, but to gain access to Asha'man and learn about them."

"ðæts wʌt wɝ duɪŋ," dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɛd. "aɪv bɪn lɝnɪŋ mʌtʃ ðiz læs fju wiks. wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ?"

"That's what we're doing," Javindhra said. "I've been learning much these last few weeks. What have you been doing?"

pɛvɑɹə dɪd nɑt ɹaɪz tə ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz toʊn. mʌst ʃi bi soʊ kɑntʃɹɛɹi? pɛvɑɹə hæd liɾɝʃɪp ə ðɪs tim, ən ði ʌðɝz wəd dɪfɝ tə hɝ. bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn min ðət ðeɪ wəɾ ɔlweɪz bi plɛzən əbaʊɾ ɪt.

Pevara did not rise to the other woman's tone. Must she be so contrary? Pevara had leadership of this team, and the others would defer to her. But it didn't mean that they would always be pleasant about it.

"ðɪs əz bɪn ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ɑpɝtunəɾi," dʒəvɪnʒɹə kəntɪnjud, skænɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz.

"This has been an interesting opportunity," Javindhra continued, scanning the Tower grounds.

"æn aɪ də θɪŋk hɪl jild ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə fʊl æʃəmən."

"And I do think he will yield eventually on the subject of full Asha'man."

pɛvɑɹə fɹaʊnd. dʒəvɪnʒɹə kʊdn ɑnəsli θɪŋk ðæt, kəd ʃi? æftɝ haʊ stʌbɝn teɪm hæd bɪn? jɛs, pɛvɑɹə hæd jildəd tə sədʒɛstʃənz ðət ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ, tə lɝn ʌv ɪts wɝkɪŋz ən æsk teɪm tə əlaʊ ðɛm æksɛs tə ðə mɔɹ paʊɝfəl æʃəmən. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs naʊ hi wəd nɑt ɡɪv ɪn. ʃʊɹli dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɔ ðæt.

Pevara frowned. Javindhra couldn't honestly think that, could she? After how stubborn Taim had been? Yes, Pevara had yielded to suggestions that they remain in the Black Tower a little longer, to learn of its workings and ask Taim to allow them access to the more powerful Asha'man. But it was obvious now he would not give in. Surely Javindhra saw that.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, pɛvɑɹə wɑz hævɪŋ ɡɹeɪt dɪfəkəlti ɹiɾɪŋ dʒəvɪnʒɹə leɪtli. ɝɪdʒənəli, ðə wʊmən hæd simd əɡɛns kʌmɪŋ tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, oʊnli əɡɹiɪŋ tə ðə mɪʃən kəz ðə haɪəs hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪt. jɛt naʊ ʃi ɔfɝd ɹizənz tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ.

Unfortunately, Pevara was having great difficulty reading Javindhra lately. Originally, the woman had seemed against coming to the Black Tower, only agreeing to the mission because the Highest had ordered it. Yet now she offered reasons to remain here.

"dʒəvɪnʒɹə," pɛvɑɹə sɛd, stɛpɪŋ kloʊsɝ. "ju hɝd wʌɾ i sɛd. wi naʊ nid pɝmɪʃən tə liv. ðɪs pleɪs ɪz tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ə keɪdʒ."

"Javindhra," Pevara said, stepping closer. "You heard what he said. We now need permission to leave. This place is turning into a cage."

"aɪ θɪŋk, wɝ seɪf," dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ə hænd. "hi dʌznt noʊ wɪv ɡeɪtweɪz."

"I think, we're safe," Javindhra said, waving a hand. "He doesn't know we have gateways."

"soʊ fɑɹ əz wi noʊ," pɛvɑɹə sɛd.

"So far as we know," Pevara said.

"ɪf jə ɔɹɾɝ ɪt, aɪm ʃʊɹ ði ʌðɝz wɪl ɡoʊ," dʒəvɪnʒɹə sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ ɪntɛndəd tə kəntɪnju tə juz ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə lɝn."

"If you order it, I'm sure the others will go," Javindhra said. "But I intended to continue to use the opportunity to learn."

pɛvɑɹə tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ɪnsʌfɝəbəl wʊmən! ʃʊɹli ʃi wɑznt ɡoʊɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ əz tə ɪɡnɔɹ pɛvɑɹəz liɾɝʃɪp ə ðə ɡɹup? æftɝ ðə haɪəs hɝsɛlf hæd pleɪs pɛvɑɹə ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ? laɪt, bʌt dʒəvɪnʒɹə wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪɹæɾɪk.

Pevara took a deep breath. Insufferable woman! Surely she wasn't going so far as to ignore Pevara's leadership of the group? After the Highest herself had placed Pevara in charge? Light, but Javindhra was growing erratic.

ðeɪ pɑɹɾəd wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd, pɛvɑɹə spɪnɪŋ ən wɔkɪŋ bæk daʊn ðə pæθ. ʃi kɛpt əɹ tɛmpɝ wɪð dɪfəkəlti. ðət læst steɪtmən hæd bɪn kloʊz tə aʊtʃɹaɪt dɪfaɪəns! wɛl, ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə dɪsəbeɪ ən ɹɪmeɪn, soʊ bi ɪt. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bi ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

They parted without another word, Pevara spinning and walking back down the path. She kept her temper with difficulty. That last statement had been close to outright defiance! Well, if she wanted to disobey and remain, so be it. It was time to be returning to the White Tower.

mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts wɔkt ɔl ɝaʊn hɝ. mɛni nɑɾəd wɪð ðoʊz tu-əbsikwiəs ɡɹɪnz ə feɪn ɹɪspɛkt. hɝ wiks hɪɹ hæd nɑt dʌn ɛniθɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ɝaʊn ðiz mɛn. ʃi wəd meɪk ə fju ʌv əm wɔɹɾɝz. θɹi. ʃi kəd hændəl θɹi, kʊdnt ʃi?

Men in black coats walked all around her. Many nodded with those too-obsequious grins of feigned respect. Her weeks here had not done anything to make her more comfortable around these men. She would make a few of them Warders. Three. She could handle three, couldn't she?

ðoʊz dɑɹk ɪkspɹɛʃənz, laɪk ði aɪz ʌv ɛksəkjuʃənɝz waɪl weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə nɛks nɛk tə laɪn ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. ðə weɪ səm ə ðɛm mʌɾɝd tə ðɛmsɛlvz, əɹ dʒʌmpt ət ʃædoʊz, əɹ hɛl ðɛɹ hɛdz ən lʊk deɪzd. ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ðə vɛɹi pɪɾ ə mædnəs ɪtsɛlf, ən ɪt meɪɾ əɹ skɪn kɹip əz ɪf kʌvɝɾ ɪn kæɾəpɪlɝz. ʃi kʊdn hɛlp kwɪkənɪŋ əɹ peɪs. noʊ, ʃi θɔt. / kæn liv dʒəvɪnʒɹə hɪɹ, nɑt wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ wʌn mɔɹ taɪm. pɛvɑɹə wəɾ ɪkspleɪn tə ði ʌðɝz, ɡɪv əm ði ɔɹɾɝ tə liv. ðən ʃiɾ æsk ðɛm, tɑɹnə fɝst, tə əpɹoʊtʃ dʒəvɪnʒɹə. ʃʊɹli ðɛɹ junaɪɾəd ɑɹɡjəməns wəd kənvɪns hɝ.

Those dark expressions, like the eyes of executioners while waiting for the next neck to line up before them. The way some of them muttered to themselves, or jumped at shadows, or held their heads and looked dazed. She stood in the very pit of madness itself, and it made her skin creep as if covered in caterpillars. She couldn't help quickening her pace. No, she thought. / can't leave Javindhra here, not without trying one more time. Pevara would explain to the others, give them the order to leave. Then she'd ask them, Tarna first, to approach Javindhra. Surely their united arguments would convince her.

pɛvɑɹə ɹitʃt ðə hʌts ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɡɪvən. ʃi pɝpəsli dɪd nɑt lʊk tə ðə saɪd, təwɔɹd ðə laɪn ə smɔl bɪldɪŋz wɛɹ ðə bɑndəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪd ðɛɹ hoʊmz. ʃid hɝd wʌt səm ə ðɛm wɝ duɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ æʃəmən juzɪŋ . . . vɛɹiəs mɛθədz. ðət meɪɾ əɹ skɪn kɹɔl, tu. waɪl ʃi θɔt moʊst ɹɛdz hæd tu hɑɹʃ ən əpɪnjən ə mɛn, wʌt ðoʊz wɪmən dɪd kɹɔs ðə laɪn wɪð ə hidləs lip.

Pevara reached the huts they had been given. She purposely did not look to the side, toward the line of small buildings where the bonded Aes Sedai made their homes. She'd heard what some of them were doing, trying to control their Asha'man using . . . various methods. That made her skin crawl, too. While she thought most Reds had too harsh an opinion of men, what those women did crossed the line with a heedless leap.

ʃi stɛpt ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hʌt, ən ðəɹ faʊn tɑɹnə ət ðə dɛsk ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə lɛɾɝ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd tə ʃɛɹ ðɛɹ hʌts, ən pɛvɑɹə hæd pɪk tɑɹnə spəsɪfɪkli. pɛvɑɹə maɪɾ əv bɪn meɪd liɾɝ ə ðɪs ɡɹup, bʌt tɑɹnə wɑz kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz. ðə pɑlətɪks ə ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɛkspədɪʃən wɝ vɛɹi dɛləkət, wɪð soʊ mɛni ɪnfluɛntʃəl mɛmbɝz ən soʊ mɛni əpɪnjənz.

She stepped inside her hut, and there found Tarna at the desk writing a letter. The Aes Sedai had to share their huts, and Pevara had picked Tarna specifically. Pevara might have been made leader of this group, but Tarna was Keeper of the Chronicles. The politics of this particular expedition were very delicate, with so many influential members and so many opinions.

læs naɪt, tɑɹnə hæɾ əɡɹid ðəɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə liv. ʃid wɝk wɪð pɛvɑɹə ɑn ɡoʊɪŋ tə dʒəvɪnʒɹə.

Last night, Tarna had agreed that it was time to leave. She'd work with Pevara on going to Javindhra.

"teɪm əz lɑk daʊn ðə blæk taʊɝ," pɛvɑɹə sɛd kɑmli, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ bɛɾ ɪn ðə smɔl, sɝkjəlɝ tʃeɪmbɝ. "wi naʊ niɾ ɪz pɝmɪʃən tə liv. hi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑfhændɪdli, əz ɪf ɪt wɝn ɹɪli mɛn tə stɑp ʌs. dʒʌst ə ɹul hid fɝɡɑɾən tə ɡɪv əs ə blæŋkəɾ ɪksɛpʃən tə."

"Taim has locked down the Black Tower," Pevara said calmly, sitting on her bed in the small, circular chamber. "We now need his permission to leave. He said it offhandedly, as if it weren't really meant to stop us. Just a rule he'd forgotten to give us a blanket exception to."

"laɪkli, ðæts dʒʌst wʌɾ ɪt wɑz," tɑɹnə sɛd. "aɪm ʃʊɹ ɪts nʌθɪŋ."

"Likely, that's just what it was," Tarna said. "I'm sure it's nothing."

pɛvɑɹə fɛl stɪl. wʌt? ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn. "dʒəvɪnʒɹə stɪl ɪɹæʃənəli θɪŋks hɪl tʃeɪnʒ ɪz maɪn ɑn lɛɾɪŋ əs bɑn fʊl æʃəmən. ɪts taɪm tə bɑn dɛɾəkeɪtəd ən liv, bʌt ʃiz hɪntəd ðət ʃɪl ɹɪmeɪn ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə maɪ ɪntɛntʃənz. aɪ wɑn jə tə spik tə hɝ."

Pevara fell still. What? She tried again. "Javindhra still irrationally thinks he will change his mind on letting us bond full Asha'man. It's time to bond Dedicated and leave, but she's hinted that she'll remain regardless of my intentions. I want you to speak to her."

"æktʃəli ," tɑɹnə sɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə ɹaɪt, "aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn wʌt wi dɪskʌs læs naɪt.

"Actually," Tarna said, continuing to write, "I've been thinking on what we discussed last night.

pɝhæps aɪ wɑz heɪsti. ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ tə lɝn hɪɹ, ən ðəɹ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ ə ðə ɹɛbəlz aʊtsaɪd. ɪf wi liv, ðəl bɑn æʃəmən, wɪtʃ ʃəd nɑt bi əlaʊd."

Perhaps I was hasty. There is much to learn here, and there is the matter of the rebels outside. If we leave, they will bond Asha'man, which should not be allowed."

ðə wʊmən lʊkt ʌp, ən pɛvɑɹə fɹoʊz. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɝ- ɛn ɪn tɑɹnəz aɪz, sʌmθɪŋ koʊld. ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə dɪstənt wʌn, bʌt ðɪs wɑz wɝs.

The woman looked up, and Pevara froze. There was something differ- ent in Tarna's eyes, something cold. She'd always been a distant one, but this was worse.

tɑɹnə smaɪld, ə ɡɹɪmɑs ðət lʊkt kəmplitli ənnætʃɹəl ɑn əɹ feɪs. laɪk ðə smaɪl ɑn ðə lɪps ʌv ə kɔɹps. ʃi tɝn bæk tə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ.

Tarna smiled, a grimace that looked completely unnatural on her face. Like the smile on the lips of a corpse. She turned back to her writing.

sʌmθɪŋ ɪz vɛɹi, vɛɹi ɹɔŋ hɪɹ, pɛvɑɹə θɔt. "wɛl, jə meɪ bi ɹaɪt," ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf seɪɪŋ. hɝ maʊθ wɝkt, ðoʊ hɝ maɪn ɹild. "ðɪs ɛkspədɪʃən wɑz jəɹ sədʒɛstʃən, æftɝ ɔl. əl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt fɝðɝ. ɪf jəl ɪkskjus mi."

Something is very, very wrong here, Pevara thought. "Well, you may be right," she found herself saying. Her mouth worked, though her mind reeled. "This expedition was your suggestion, after all. I will think on it further. If you'll excuse me."

tɑɹnə weɪvd æmbɪveɪlənli. pɛvɑɹə stʊd, jɪɹz əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kipɪŋ əɹ pɹoʊfaʊnd wɝi fɹəm ʃoʊɪŋ ɪn əɹ pɑstʃɝ. ʃi stɛpt aʊtsaɪd, ðən wɔkt istwɝd, əlɔŋ ði ənfɪnɪʃt wɔl.

Tarna waved ambivalently. Pevara stood, years as an Aes Sedai keeping her profound worry from showing in her posture. She stepped outside, then walked eastward, along the unfinished wall.

jɛs, ɡɑɹd steɪʃənz hæd bɪn sɛɾ ʌp ɹɛɡjəlɝli. ɝliɝ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðoʊz hædn bɪn mænd. naʊ ðeɪ wɝ, wɪð mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. wʌn ə ðoʊz mɛn kəd stʃɹaɪk əɹ dɛd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɹɪspɑnd. ʃi kʊdn si ðɛɹ wivz, ən ʃi kʊdn stʃɹaɪk fɝst, kəz ə hɝ oʊðz.

Yes, guard stations had been set up regularly. Earlier this morning, those hadn't been manned. Now they were, with men who could channel. One of those men could strike her dead before she could respond. She couldn't see their weaves, and she couldn't strike first, because of her oaths.

ʃi tɝn ən wɔk tə ə smɔl stæn ə tʃɹiz, ə pleɪs ðət wɑz tə bɪkʌm ə ɡɑɹɾən. ɪnsaɪd, ʃi sæt daʊn ɑn ə stʌmp, bɹiðɪŋ dipli. ðə koʊlnəs - ɔlmoʊs laɪfləsnəs - ʃid sin ɪn tɑɹnəz aɪz stɪl tʃɪl hɝ.

She turned and walked to a small stand of trees, a place that was to become a garden. Inside, she sat down on a stump, breathing deeply. The coldness - almost lifelessness - she'd seen in Tarna's eyes still chilled her.

pɛvɑɹə hæd bɪn ɔɹɾɝd baɪ ðə haɪəs nɑt tə ɹɪsk ɡeɪtweɪz ənlɛs ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən wɝ daɪɹ. ðɪs sim laɪk ə daɪɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən tə hɝ. ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən woʊv ðə pɹɑpɝ wiv.

Pevara had been ordered by the Highest not to risk gateways unless the situation were dire. This seemed like a dire situation to her. She embraced the Source and wove the proper weave.

ðə wiv fɛl əpɑɹt ðə moʊmənt ʃi kəmpliɾəd ɪt. noʊ ɡeɪtweɪ fɔɹmd. aɪz waɪd, ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, bʌt ɡɑt ðə seɪm ɹɪzʌlt. ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ ʌðɝ wivz, ən ðeɪ wɝkt, bʌt ɡeɪtweɪz feɪld ɛvɹi taɪm.

The weave fell apart the moment she completed it. No gateway formed. Eyes wide, she tried again, but got the same result. She tried other weaves, and they worked, but gateways failed every time.

hɝ tʃɪl bɪkeɪm fɹɔst wɪðɪn hɝ. ʃi wɑz tʃɹæpt.

Her chill became frost within her. She was trapped.

ðeɪ ɔl wɝ.

They all were.

pɛɹɪn klæsp hænz wɪð mæt. "ɡʊd lʌk, maɪ fɹɛnd."

Perrin clasped hands with Mat. "Good luck, my friend."

mæt ɡɹɪnd, tʌɡɪŋ daʊn ðə bɹɔd bɹɪm ə hɪz dɑɹk hæt. "lʌk? aɪ hoʊp ðɪs ɔl kʌmz daʊn tə lʌk. aɪm ɡʊd wɪð lʌk."

Mat grinned, tugging down the broad brim of his dark hat. "Luck? I hope this all comes down to luck. I'm good with luck."

mæt kæɹiɾ ə bʌlʒɪŋ pæk oʊvɝ wʌn ʃoʊldɝ, əz dɪd ðə boʊni, nɑɹl mæn ðət mæt hæɾ ɪntʃɹədust əz noʊl. θɔɹn hæɾ ɪz hɑɹp ɑn ɪz bæk ən ə sɪməlɝ pæk. pɛɹɪn stɪl wɑzn klɪɹ ɑn wʌt ðeɪ wɝ bɹɪŋɪŋ. mæt oʊnli plæn tə bi ət ðə taʊɝ fəɹ ə fju deɪz, soʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ə lɑɾ ə səplaɪz.

Mat carried a bulging pack over one shoulder, as did the bony, gnarled man that Mat had introduced as Noal. Thorn had his harp on his back and a similar pack. Perrin still wasn't clear on what they were bringing. Mat only planned to be at the tower for a few days, so there was no need for a lot of supplies.

ðə smɔl ɡɹup stʊɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊn aʊtsaɪd pɛɹɪnz kæmp. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, pɛɹɪnz pipəl ʃaʊɾəd bæk ən fɔɹθ, bɹeɪkɪŋ daʊn ðə kæmp. nʌn hæɾ ɛni ɪŋklɪŋ ə haʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðɪs deɪ kəd pɹuv. mwɑ-ɹeɪn. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz əlaɪv. laɪt, lɛɾ ɪt bi soʊ.

The small group stood on the Traveling ground outside Perrin's camp. Behind them, Perrin's people shouted back and forth, breaking down the camp. None had any inkling of how important this day could prove. Moi-raine. Moiraine was alive. Light, let it be so.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən aɪ kæn kənvɪns jə tə teɪk mɔɹ hɛlp?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Are you certain I can't convince you to take more help?" Perrin asked.

mæt nɑɾəd. "sɑɹi. ðiz θɪŋz . . . wɛl, ðeɪ tɛn tə bi pɝtɪkjəlɝ. ðə noʊt wɑz klɪɹ. oʊnli θɹi ʌv əs kən ɛntɝ, ʌðɝwaɪz wɪl feɪl. ɪf wi feɪl ɛniweɪ . . . wɛl, aɪ ɡɛs ɪɾəl bi hɝ oʊn blʌɾi fɔl ðɛn, woʊn ɪt?"

Mat nodded. "Sorry. These things . . . well, they tend to be particular. The note was clear. Only three of us can enter, otherwise we'll fail. If we fail anyway . . . well, I guess it will be her own bloody fault then, won't it?"

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. "dʒʌs bi kɛɹfəl. aɪm ɪkspɛktɪŋ ənʌðɝ hɛlpɪŋ fɹəm jəɹ paʊtʃ ə təbæk ət mæstɝ dɛnizəlz pleɪs wən jə ɹɪtɝn."

Perrin frowned. "Just be careful. I'm expecting another helping from your pouch of tabac at Master Denezel's place when you return."

"jul əv ɪt," θɔɹn sɛd, teɪkɪŋ pɛɹɪnz ɔfɝd hænd. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, smaɪlɪŋ, ə feɪn twɪŋkəl ɪn ɪz aɪz.

"You'll have it," Thorn said, taking Perrin's offered hand. He hesitated, smiling, a faint twinkle in his eyes.

"wʌt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What?" Perrin asked.

θɔɹn ɹipəzɪʃən ɪz pæk. "ɪz ɛvɹi læs fɑɹmbɔɪ aɪ noʊ gɑnə tʃɹænsfɔɹm ɪndə ə noʊbəlmən baɪ ðə taɪm ðɪs ɪz θɹu?"

Thorn repositioned his pack. "Is every last farmboy I know going to transform into a nobleman by the time this is through?"

"ɪm noʊ noʊbəlmən," mæt sɛd.

"I'm no nobleman," Mat said.

"oʊ?" tɑm æskt. "pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz?"

"Oh?" Thom asked. "Prince of the Ravens?"

mæt pʊld ɪz hæt daʊn. "pipəl kən kɔl mi wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt. ðət dʌzn min aɪm wʌn ə ðɛm."

Mat pulled his hat down. "People can call me what they want. That doesn't mean I'm one of them."

"æktʃəli ," tɑm sɛd, "ɪt - "

"Actually," Thom said, "it - "

"oʊpən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ soʊ wi kən ɡɛt ɡoʊɪŋ," mæt sɛd. "noʊ mɔɹ nɑnsɛns."

"Open the gateway so we can get going," Mat said. "No more nonsense."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd tə ɡɹeɪɾi. ði ɛɹ ɹɛnt, ə twɪstɪŋ bim ə laɪɾ oʊpənɪŋ ə pɔɹɾəl ðəɾ oʊvɝlʊkt ə bɹɔd, sloʊ-muvɪŋ ɹɪvɝ. "ðɪs ɪz əz kloʊz əz i kən ɡɛt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æt list, nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ə bɛɾɝ dɪskɹɪpʃən ə ðə pleɪs."

Perrin nodded to Grady. The air rent, a twisting beam of light opening a portal that overlooked a broad, slow-moving river. "This is as close as he can get," Perrin said. "At least, not without a better description of the place."

"ɪɾəl du," mæt sɛd, poʊkɪŋ ɪz hɛd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. "jul oʊpən wʌn fəɹ əs tə ɡɛt bæk?"

"It'll do," Mat said, poking his head through the gateway. "You'll open one for us to get back?"

"itʃ deɪ ət nun," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, ɹɪpiɾɪŋ pɛɹɪnz ɔɹɾɝz tə hɪm. "ɪntu ðəɾ ɪɡzæk spɑt." hi smaɪld. "teɪk kɛɹ jə doʊnt ɡɛt jəɹ toʊz kʌɾ ɔf wən ɪɾ əpɪɹz, mæstɝ kɔθən."

"Each day at noon," Grady said, repeating Perrin's orders to him. "Into that exact spot." He smiled. "Take care you don't get your toes cut off when it appears, Master Cauthon."

"aɪl də maɪ bɛst," mæt sɛd. "aɪm ətætʃt tə ðoʊz toʊz." hi tʊk ə bɹɛθ ən stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. kwaɪət noʊl fɑloʊd, smɛlɪŋ ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən. ðət wʌn wɑz ə lɑt tʌfɝ ðən i lʊkt.

"I'll do my best," Mat said. "I'm attached to those toes." He took a breath and stepped through the gateway. Quiet Noal followed, smelling of determination. That one was a lot tougher than he looked.

tɑm nɑɾəd tə pɛɹɪn, mʌstæʃɪz wæɡɪŋ, ðən hɑp θɹu. hi wɑz spɹaɪ, ðoʊ hi stɪl bɔɹ ðə stɪf lɛɡ fɹəm faɪɾɪŋ ðət feɪd tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ.

Thom nodded to Perrin, mustaches wagging, then hopped through. He was spry, though he still bore the stiff leg from fighting that Fade two years ago.

laɪt ɡaɪd ju, pɛɹɪn pɹeɪd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə ðə θɹi əz ðeɪ tʃɹʌdʒd əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝz bæŋk.

Light guide you, Perrin prayed, raising a hand to the three as they trudged along the river's bank.

mɔɪɹeɪn. pɛɹɪn ʃəd sɛnd wɝd tə ɹænd. ðə kʌlɝz əpɪɹd, ʃoʊɪŋ ɹænd spikɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɹup ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. bʌt ... noʊ. pɛɹɪn kʊdn tɛl ɹænd əntɪl i wɑz sɝɾən ʃi lɪvd. tə də ʌðɝwaɪz wəd bi tu kɹuəl, ən wəd bi ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən fəɹ ɹænd tə mɛɾəl ɪn mæts mɪʃən.

Moiraine. Perrin should send word to Rand. The colors appeared, showing Rand speaking with a group of Borderlanders. But ... no. Perrin couldn't tell Rand until he was certain she lived. To do otherwise would be too cruel, and would be an invitation for Rand to meddle in Mat's mission.

pɛɹɪn tɝn əz ðə pɔɹɾəl kloʊzd. əz i stɛpt, hi fɛlt ə feɪn θɹɑbɪŋ fɹəm ɪz lɛɡ, wɛɹ sleɪɝz æɹoʊ hæd hɪt hɪm. hi hæd bɪn hild əɹ ðət waʊnd, ən fɹəm wʌt hid bɪn eɪbəl tə tɛl, ðə hilɪŋ hæd bɪn kəmplit. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɪnʒɝi. bʌɾ ɪz lɛɡ . . . ɪt fɛlt laɪk ɪt kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə waʊn ɛniweɪ. ɪt wɑz laɪk ə ʃædoʊ, vɛɹi feɪnt, ɔlmoʊst ənnɑɾəsəbəl.

Perrin turned as the portal closed. As he stepped, he felt a faint throbbing from his leg, where Slayer's arrow had hit him. He had been Healed or that wound, and from what he'd been able to tell, the Healing had been complete. There was no injury. But his leg . . . it felt like it could remember the wound anyway. It was like a shadow, very faint, almost unnoticeable.

feɪl wɔkt ʌp tə hɪm, hɝ feɪs kjʊɹiəs. ɡɔl wɑz wɪð hɝ, ən pɝ-ɹɪn smaɪld ət ðə weɪ hi kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət beɪn ən kiæd. wʌn kæɹiɾ ɪz spɪɹz, ði ʌðɝ ɪz baʊ. soʊ ðəɾ i dɪdn əv tə, əpɛɹənli.

Faile walked up to him, her face curious. Gaul was with her, and Per-rin smiled at the way he kept glancing over his shoulder at Bain and Chiad. One carried his spears, the other his bow. So that he didn't have to, apparently.

"aɪ mɪs ðə sɛndɔf?" feɪl æskt.

ʃi snɪft. "meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɪz ə bæɾ ɪnfluəns. aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd i dɪdn dʒɹæɡ jə ɔf tə ənʌðɝ tævɝn bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ."

əmjuzɪŋli, ðə kʌlɝz əpɪɹd, ʃoʊɪŋ ɪm mæt - hu hæd dʒʌs lɛft - wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ.

Amusingly, the colors appeared, showing him Mat - who had just left - walking along the river.

"hiz nɑɾ əz bæɾ əz ɔl ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɑɹ wi ɹɛɾi?"

"ɝɑvin əz ɛvɹiwʌn ɔɹɡənaɪzd ən muvɪŋ," feɪl sɛd. "wi ʃəd bi ɹɛɾi tə mɑɹtʃ wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ."

"Aravine has everyone organized and moving," Faile said. "We should be ready to march within the hour."

ðət pɹuvd ə ɡʊɾ ɛstəmət. ɪn əbaʊɾ ə hæf-aʊɝ, pɛɹɪn stʊd tə ðə saɪɾ əz ən ɪnɔɹməs ɡeɪtweɪ splɪt ði ɛɹ, kɹieɪɾəd baɪ ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild lɪŋk təɡɛðɝ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɛdʒɹə.

That proved a good estimate. In about a half-hour, Perrin stood to the side as an enormous gateway split the air, created by Grady and Neald linked together with the Aes Sedai and Edarra.

noʊbɑdi hæd kwɛstʃən pɛɹɪnz dɪsɪʒən tə muv. ɪf ɹænd wɑz tʃɹævlɪŋ tə ðɪs pleɪs noʊn əz ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ, ðən ðət wɑz wɛɹ pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə bi. ɪt wɑz wɛɹ i niɾəd tə bi.

Nobody had questioned Perrin's decision to move. If Rand was traveling to this place known as the Field of Merrilor, then that was where Perrin wanted to be. It was where he needed to be.

ðə læn bɪɑn ðɪs ɡeɪtweɪ mɔɹ ɹʌɡəd ðən sʌðɝn ændɝ. fjuɝ tʃɹiz, mɔɹ pɹɛɹi ɡɹæs.

The land beyond this gateway more rugged than southern Andor. Fewer trees, more prairie grass.

səm ɹuənz leɪ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ði oʊpən ɛɹiə bɪfɔɹ əm wɑz fɪld wɪð tɛns, bænɝz, ən kæmps.

Some ruins lay in the distance. The open area before them was filled with tents, banners, and camps.

ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ɛɡwinz koʊəlɪʃən wɑz ɡæðɝd.

It looked as if Egwene's coalition was gathered.

ɡɹeɪɾi pɪɹd θɹu, ðən wɪsəl sɔfli. "haʊ mɛni pipəl ɪz ðæt?"

"ðoʊz ɑɹ ðə kɹɛsən munz ə tɛɹ," pɛɹɪn noʊɾəd, pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə bænɝ. "æn ðæts ɪljən. kæmpt ɑn ɑpəzət saɪdz ə ðə fild." ə ɡɹin bænɝ sɛt wɪð naɪn ɡoʊldən biz mɑɹk ðəɾ ɑɹmi.

"Those are the Crescent Moons of Tear," Perrin noted, pointing toward a banner. "And that's Illian. Camped on opposite sides of the field." A green banner set with nine golden bees marked that army.

"ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə kɛɹhinɪn haʊsəz," feɪl sɛd, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ɔf ðə ɹaɪz. "nɑɾ ə fju il. . .

"A large number of Cairhienin Houses," Faile said, looking out off the rise. "Not a few Aiel. . .

noʊ bɔɹɾɝləndɝ flæɡz."

No Borderlander flags."

"aɪv nɛvɝ sin soʊ mɛni tʃɹups ɪn wʌn pleɪs," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd.

"I've never seen so many troops in one place," Grady said.

ɪts ɹɪli hæpənɪŋ, pɛɹɪn θɔt, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ. ðə læs bæɾəl.

It's really happening, Perrin thought, heart thumping. The Last Battle.

"du jə θɪŋk ðəl bi ɪnʌf tə stɑp ɹænd?" feɪl æskt. "tə hɛlp əs kip ɪm fɹəm bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə silz?"

"Do you think they'll be enough to stop Rand?" Faile asked. "To help us keep him from breaking the seals?"

"hɛlp ʌs?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"Help us?" Perrin asked.

"ju toʊld ɪleɪn ðət jud ɡoʊ tə ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ," feɪl sɛd. "bɪkɔz ʌv wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ æskt."

"You told Elayne that you'd go to the Field of Merrilor," Faile said. "Because of what Egwene had asked."

"oʊ, aɪ toʊld əɹ aɪ niɾəd tə bi ðɛɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ sɛɾ aɪ wɑz gɑnə teɪk ɛɡwinz saɪd. aɪ tʃɹʌst ɹænd, feɪl, ən ɪt simz ɹaɪt tə mi ðət hid nid tə bɹeɪk ðə silz. ɪts laɪk meɪkɪŋ ə sɔɹd. jə juʒəwəli doʊnt wɑnə fɔɹdʒ wʌn aʊɾ ə ðə pisəz ʌv ə bɹoʊkən ən ɹuənd wɛpən jə ɡɛt nu ɡʊd stil tə meɪk ɪt. ɹæðɝ ðən pætʃ ði oʊl silz, hɪl nid tə meɪk nu wʌnz."

"Oh, I told her I needed to be there," Perrin said. "But I never said I was going to take Egwene's side. I trust Rand, Faile, and it seems right to me that he'd need to break the seals. It's like making a sword. You usually don't want to forge one out of the pieces of a broken and ruined weapon You get new good steel to make it. Rather than patch the old seals, he'll need to make new ones."

"pɝhæps," feɪl sɛd. "bʌt ðɪs ɪz gɑnə bi ə faɪn laɪn tə wɔk. soʊ mɛni ɑɹmiz ɪn wʌn pleɪs. ɪf səm saɪd wɪð ɹænd ən ʌðɝz wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ . . ."

"Perhaps," Faile said. "But this is going to be a fine line to walk. So many armies in one place. If some side with Rand and others with the White Tower . . ."

noʊbɑdi wəd wɪn ɪf ðeɪ tɝn əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. wɛl, pɛɹɪn wəɾ əv tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət dɪdn hæpən.

Nobody would win if they turned against one another. Well, Perrin would have to make sure that didn't happen.

ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝɾ ɪn laɪnz, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə mɑɹtʃ. pɛɹɪn tɝn tə ðɛm. "ɹæn sɛn əs əweɪ tə sɝtʃ fəɹ ən ɛnəmi," hi bɛloʊd. "wi ɹɪtɝn tə hɪm hævɪŋ faʊn ælaɪz. ɔnwɝd, tə ðə læs bæɾəl!"

The soldiers were already gathered in lines, preparing to march. Perrin turned to them. "Rand sent us away to search for an enemy," he bellowed. "We return to him having found allies. Onward, to the Last Battle!"

oʊnli ðə wʌnz ət ðə fɹʌn kəd hɪɹ hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ tʃɪɹɾ ən pæs ðə wɝd bæk. ɹænd əɹ ɪleɪn wʊɾə ɡɪvən ə fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪnspaɪɹɪŋ spitʃ. bʌt pɛɹɪn wɑzn ðɛm. hiɾ əv tə də θɪŋz ɪz weɪ.

Only the ones at the front could hear him, but they cheered and passed the word back. Rand or Elayne would have given a far more inspiring speech. But Perrin wasn't them. He'd have to do things his way.

"ɝɑvin," pɛɹɪn kɔl tə ðə plʌmp ɑmɑdɪʃən. "ɡoʊ θɹu ən meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət noʊbɑdi faɪts oʊvɝ wɛɹ tə sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ kæmps."

"Aravine," Perrin called to the plump Amadician. "Go through and make sure that nobody fights over where to set up their camps."

"jɛs, lɔɹd ɡoʊldeɪniz."

"Yes, Lord Goldeneyes."

"kip əs əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɑɹmiz fəɹ naʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ. "hæv səlɪn ən ɡɔl pɪk ə ɡʊd saɪt. pæs ðə wɝd tə itʃ ə ði ɑɹmiz əz wi sɛɾ ʌp. wɝ nɑt tə ɪntɝækt wɪð, əɹ lʊk ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ æt, ɛni ʌv ðoʊz ʌðɝ fɔɹsɪz. ən doʊn lɛt pipəl ɡoʊ wɑndɝɪŋ ɔf saʊθwɝɾ iðɝ!

"Keep us away from the other armies for now," Perrin said, pointing. "Have Sulin and Gaul pick a good site. Pass the word to each of the armies as we set up. We're not to interact with, or look the wrong way at, any of those other forces. And don't let people go wandering off southward either!

wɝ nɑɾ ɪn ðə wɪldɝnəs ɛnimɔɹ, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðə loʊkəl fɑɹmɝz kəmpleɪnɪŋ ə mɪstʃəf."

We're not in the wilderness anymore, and I don't want the local farmers complaining of mischief."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," ʃi sɛd.

"Yes, my Lord," she said.

hid nɛvɝ æskt ɝɑvin waɪ ʃi dɪdn dʒɔɪn wʌn ə ðə ɡɹups ðət hæd bɪn sɛn bæk tə ɑmɑdɪʃiə. ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli kəz ə ðə sintʃæn, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli noʊbəl, bʌt dɪdn seɪ mʌtʃ ə hɝ pæst. hi wɑz ɡlæd tə hæv hɝ. əz ɪz kæmp stuɝd, ʃi wɑz ɪz lieɪzɑn bɪtwin ðə vɛɹiəs fækʃənz ðət meɪɾ ʌp ɪz ɑɹmi.

He'd never asked Aravine why she didn't join one of the groups that had been sent back to Amadicia. It was probably because of the Seanchan, though. She was obviously noble, but didn't say much of her past. He was glad to have her. As his camp steward, she was his liaison between the various factions that made up his army.

ðə wʊlf ɡɑɹd hæd dʒɹɔn fɝs lɑt, soʊ ðeɪ lɛd ðə weɪ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðə lɑɹdʒ kɑləm bɪɡæn tə muv. pɛɹɪn wɛn daʊn ðə laɪn, ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz, moʊsli ɹiɪnfɔɹsɪŋ ðəɾ i dɪdnt wɑn tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ðə loʊkəlz əɹ ði ʌðɝ ɑɹmiz. hi stɑpt əz i mɛt waɪtkloʊks weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn.

The Wolf Guard had drawn first lot, so they led the way through the gateway. The large column began to move. Perrin went down the line, giving orders, mostly reinforcing that he didn't want trouble with the locals or the other armies. He stopped as he met Whitecloaks waiting their turn.

bɹəleɪn wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɛks tə ɡɑləɾ əɡɛn; ðeɪ sim vɛɹi əminəbli lɔst ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən. laɪt, bʌt ðə wʊmən hæd spɛn pɹɪɾi mʌtʃ ɛvɹi weɪkɪŋ aʊɝ wɪð ɡɑləd ðiz læs fju deɪz.

Berelain was riding next to Galad again; they seemed very amenably lost in conversation. Light, but the woman had spent pretty much every waking hour with Galad these last few days.

pɛɹɪn hædn pʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks ən minɝz təɡɛðɝ, jɛt ðeɪ sim tə hæv sʌmhaʊ ɛndəɾ ʌp ðət weɪ. əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd muvɪŋ, ɡɑlədz waɪtkloʊks ɹoʊɾ ɪn ə pɝfək laɪn, fɔɹ əkɹɔs, ðɛɹ waɪt tɑbɝdz sɛt wɪð sʌnbɝsts. pɛɹɪn stɪl hæɾ ə ɡʌt ɹiækʃən əkɪn tə pænɪk wɛnɛvɝ i sɔ ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪd meɪd sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli lɪɾəl tʃɹʌbəl sɪns ðə tʃɹaɪəl.

Perrin hadn't put the Whitecloaks and Mayeners together, yet they seemed to have somehow ended up that way. As they started moving, Galad's Whitecloaks rode in a perfect line, four across, their white tabards set with sunbursts. Perrin still had a gut reaction akin to panic whenever he saw them, but they'd made surprisingly little trouble since the trial.

minz wɪŋd ɡɑɹd ɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ɡælɛn dʒʌs bɪhaɪn bɹəleɪn, ðɛɹ lænsɪz hɛl haɪ. ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz keɪm fɹəm ðə lænsɪz, ən bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlmz wɝ ʃaɪn tə pɝfɛkʃən.

Mayene's Winged Guard rode along the other side, Gallenne just behind Berelain, their lances held high. Red streamers came from the lances, and breastplates and helms were shined to perfection.

ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi tə pɝeɪd. ən meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ. ɪf jə wɝ gɑnə ɹaɪd tə ðə læs bæɾəl, jə dɪɾ ɪt wɪð læns hɛl haɪ ən ɑɹmɝ pɑlɪʃt.

It seemed they were ready to parade. And maybe they were. If you were going to ride to the Last Battle, you did it with lance held high and armor polished.

pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn. æliændɝz ɑɹmi keɪm nɛkst, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə taɪt fɔɹmeɪʃən ə hɛvi kævəlɹi, eɪt mɛn əkɹɔs, ɑɹɡændə ət ðɛɹ hɛd. hi kɔld ɔɹɾɝz wən i sɔ pɛɹɪn, ən ðə sɝpəntaɪn kɑləm ə soʊlʒɝz tɝn ən səluɾəd.

Perrin continued on. Alliandre's army came next, riding in a tight formation of heavy cavalry, eight men across, Arganda at their head. He called orders when he saw Perrin, and the serpentine column of soldiers turned and saluted.

pɛɹɪn ɹɪtɝn ðɛɹ səlut. hiɾ æskt æliændɝ, ən ʃiɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət wɑz ði əpɹoʊpɹiət ɹɪspɑns. ʃi ɹoʊd wɪð ɑɹɡændə, saɪdsɑɾəl, ɪn ə slɪm mɝun ɡaʊn wɪð ɡoʊl tʃɹɪm. ən ɪmpɹæktəkəl aʊtfɪt fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdn bi ɪn ðə sæɾəl vɛɹi lɔŋ. θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ən əz mɛni liɡz.

Perrin returned their salute. He'd asked Alliandre, and she'd indicated that was the appropriate response. She rode with Arganda, sidesaddle, in a slim maroon gown with gold trim. An impractical outfit for riding, but they wouldn't be in the saddle very long. Three hundred paces and as many leagues.

hi kəd si hɝ sæɾəsfækʃən əz i səluɾəd əɹ soʊlʒɝz. ʃi wɑz pliz tə si hɪm stɛpɪŋ ɪndə hɪz ɹoʊl əz liɾɝ ə ðə koʊəlɪʃən. ɪn fækt, mɛni ɪn kæmp ɹiæktəd ðə seɪm weɪ. pɝhæps bɪfɔɹ, ðeɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə sɛns haʊ mʌtʃ i ɹizɛntəd liɾɝʃɪp. haʊ dɪd pipəl də ðæt, wɪθaʊt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə smɛl ɪmoʊʃənz?

He could see her satisfaction as he saluted her soldiers. She was pleased to see him stepping into his role as leader of the coalition. In fact, many in camp reacted the same way. Perhaps before, they'd been able to sense how much he resented leadership. How did people do that, without being able to smell emotions?

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," æliændɝ sɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ pæs hɪm. ʃi ɡeɪv ə boʊɪŋ sɔɹɾ ə sweɪ ðət wɑz ði ɪkwɪvələn ʌv ə hɔɹsbæk kɝtsi. "ʃʊd jə nɑt bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ?"

"Lord Perrin," Alliandre said, riding past him. She gave a bowing sort of sway that was the equivalent of a horseback curtsy. "Should you not be riding?"

"aɪ laɪk maɪ fit," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I like my feet," Perrin said.

"ɪt lʊks mɔɹ əθɔɹəteɪɾɪv wən ə kəmændɝ ɹaɪdz."

"It looks more authoritative when a commander rides."

"aɪv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə lid ðɪs bʌntʃ, æliændɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ, "bʌɾ əl də ɪt maɪ weɪ. ðət minz wɔkɪŋ wən aɪ wɑn tə." ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli ɡoʊɪŋ ə fju fit θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. hɪz fit wəd sɝv ɪm wɛl ɪnʌf.

"I've decided to lead this bunch, Alliandre," Perrin said gruffly, "but I'll do it my way. That means walking when I want to." They were only going a few feet through the gateway. His feet would serve him well enough.

"ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Of course, my Lord."

"wʌns wɝ sɛɾəld, aɪ wɑn jə tə sɛn səm mɛn bæk tə dʒəhænə. si ɪf jə kən ɹəkɹuɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls, pɪk ʌp wʌtɛvɝ sɪɾi ɡɑɹd jə hæv. bɹɪŋ əm hɪɹ. wɝ gɑnə niɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wi kən ɡɛt, ən aɪ wɑnə tʃɹeɪn əm əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl bɪfɔɹ ðɪs wɔɹ hɪts."

"Once we're settled, I want you to send some men back to Jehannah. See if you can recruit anyone else, pick up whatever city guard you have. Bring them here. We're going to need everyone we can get, and I want to train them as much as possible before this war hits."

"vɛɹi wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Very well, my Lord."

"aɪv sɛn tə min ɔlɹɛɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn tɑɹnz bɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ wʌɾ ɛkstʃɹəz i kən fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz." laɪt, bʌɾ i wɪʃt i kəd lɛɾ əm steɪ bɪhaɪnd, ɑn ðɛɹ fɑɹmz, tə lɪv ɪn pis waɪl ðə stɔɹm ɹeɪdʒd ɛlswɛɹ. bʌt ðɪs ɹɪli wɑz ði ɛnd. hi kəd fil ɪt. luz ðɪs faɪɾ ən ðeɪ lɔst ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

"I've sent to Mayene already," Perrin said. "And Tarn's been gathering what extras he can from the Two Rivers." Light, but he wished he could let them stay behind, on their farms, to live in peace while the storm raged elsewhere. But this really was the end. He could feel it. Lose this fight and they lost everything.

ðə wɝld. ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf. feɪsɪŋ ðæt, hid fil bɔɪz u kəd bɛɹli swɪŋ ə sɔɹɾ ən ɡɹændfɑðɝz u hæd tʃɹʌbəl wɔkɪŋ. ɪt twɪstəɾ ɪz stʌmək tə ədmɪɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə tʃɹuθ.

The world. The Pattern itself. Facing that, he'd field boys who could barely swing a sword and grandfathers who had trouble walking. It twisted his stomach to admit it, but it was the truth.

hi kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə laɪn ən ɡeɪv səm ɔɹɾɝz tə sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ ɡɹups. əz i wɑz fɪnɪʃɪŋ ʌp wɪð ðə læst, hi noʊɾəst ə hændfʊl ə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn pæsɪŋ baɪ. wʌn, ɑzi, hɛl ðə wʊlfhɛd bænɝ. dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ hʌŋ bæk. hi stɑpt, ðən weɪv ði ʌðɝ θɹi ɑn bɪfɔɹ tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ʌp tə pɛɹɪn.

He continued down the line and gave some orders to several other groups. As he was finishing up with the last, he noticed a handful of Two Rivers men passing by. One, Azi, held the wolfhead banner. Jori Congar hung back. He stopped, then waved the other three on before trotting up to Perrin.

wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ?

Was something wrong?

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn." dʒɔɹi dʒɹu hɪmsɛlf ʌp, lɔŋ ən læŋki, laɪk ə bɝd stændɪŋ ɑn wʌn lɛɡ. "aɪ. . . ."

"Lord Perrin." Jori drew himself up, long and lanky, like a bird standing on one leg. "I. . . ."

"wɛl?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aʊt wɪð ɪt."

"Well?" Perrin said. "Out with it."

"aɪ wɑntəd tə əpɑlədʒaɪz," dʒɔɹi sɛd, wɝdz kʌmɪŋ ɪn ə ɹʌʃ.

"I wanted to apologize," Jori said, words coming in a rush.

"fɔɹ wʌt?"

"For what?"

"fɔɹ səm θɪŋz aɪ sɛd," dʒɔɹi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əweɪ. "aɪ min, səm fulɪʃ wɝdz. ɪt wɑz æftɝ jə wɝ ɪl, jə si, ən jə wɝ teɪkən tə ðə fɝsts tɛn ən . . . wɛl, aɪ - "

"For some things I said," Jori said, looking away. "I mean, some foolish words. It was after you were ill, you see, and you were taken to the First's tent and . . . well, I - "

"ts ɔl ɹaɪt, dʒɔɹi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ ʌndɝstænd."

"Jt's all right, Jori," Perrin said. "I understand."

dʒɔɹi lʊkt ʌp, smaɪlɪŋ. "ɪts ə plɛʒɝ tə bi hɪɹ wɪð ju, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. ə ɹil plɛʒɝ. wɪl fɑloʊ jə ɛniwɛɹ, ði ʌðɝz ən aɪ."

Jori looked up, smiling. "It's a pleasure to be here with you, Lord Perrin. A real pleasure. We'll follow you anywhere, the others and I."

wɪð ðæt, dʒɔɹi səluɾəd, ðən ɹæn ɔf. pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt əɾ ɪz bɪɹd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mæn ɡoʊ. dʒɔɹi wɑz wʌn ʌv ə ɡʊd dʌzən tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn u hæɾ əpɹoʊtʃt pɛɹɪn oʊvɝ ðə læs fju deɪz tə əpɑlədʒaɪz.

With that, Jori saluted, then ran off. Perrin scratched at his beard, watching the man go. Jori was one of a good dozen Two Rivers men who had approached Perrin over the last few days to apologize.

ɪt simd ɔl ə ðɛm fɛlt ɡɪlti fəɹ spɹɛɾɪŋ ɹumɝz əbaʊt pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪn, ðoʊ nʌn wəd seɪ ɪt stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt.

It seemed all of them felt guilty for spreading rumors about Perrin and Berelain, though none would say it straight out.

blɛs feɪl fəɹ wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn ðɛɹ.

Bless Faile for what she had done there.

ɛvɹiwʌn sin tə, pɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən wɔkt ʌp ðə kɑləm ən stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

Everyone seen to, Perrin took a deep breath, then walked up the column and stepped through the gateway.

kʌm kwɪkli, ɹænd, hi θɔt, kʌlɝz blɑsəmɪŋ ɪn ɪz vɪʒən. aɪ kən fil ɪt stɑɹɾɪŋ.

Come quickly, Rand, he thought, colors blossoming in his vision. I can feel it starting.

mæt stʊd wɪð θɔɹn əɾ ɪz lɛft ən noʊl əɾ ɪz ɹaɪt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ət ðə spaɪɹ əhɛd. ə tʃɹɪklɪŋ, mjuzɪkəl stʃɹim ɡɝɡəl bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ə tʃɹɪbjətɛɹi ʌv ðə nɪɹbaɪ ɑɹɪnɛl. ə ɡɹæsi pleɪn spɹɛd bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən bɪɑn ðæt, ðə ɡɹæn ɹɪvɝ ɪtsɛlf.

Mat stood with Thorn at his left and Noal at his right, looking up through the trees at the spire ahead. A trickling, musical stream gurgled behind them, a tributary of the nearby Arinelle. A grassy plain spread behind them, and beyond that, the grand river itself.

hæɾ i pæs ðɪs weɪ bɪfɔɹ? soʊ mʌtʃ ə hɪz mɛmɹi fɹəm ðət taɪm wɑz fɹæɡməntɪd. ən jɛt, ðɪs taʊɝ ɹɪmeɪn klɪɹ ɪn ɪz maɪnd, vjud fɹəm ə dɪstəns. ivən ðə dɑɹknəs ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə ɛksaɪs ɪt fɹəm ɪz maɪnd.

Had he passed this way before? So much of his memory from that time was fragmented. And yet, this tower remained clear in his mind, viewed from a distance. Even the darkness of Shadar Logoth had not been able to excise it from his mind.
