ðə taʊɝ lʊk tə bi ʌv pjʊɹ mɛɾəl, ɪts sɑləd stil ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ði oʊvɝkæst sʌnlaɪt. mæt fɛlt ən aɪsaɪnəs bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. mɛni tʃɹævəlɝz əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ θɔɾ ɪt səm ɹɛlɪk fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. wʌɾ ɛls dɪd jə meɪk ʌv ə kɑləm ə stil ɹaɪzɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst, simɪŋli ʌnɪnhæbəɾɪd? ɪt wɑz əz ənnætʃɹəl ən aʊɾ ə pleɪs əz ðə twɪstəd ɹɛd dɔɹweɪz wɝ. ðoʊz wɔɹp ði aɪz tə lʊk ət ðɛm.

The tower looked to be of pure metal, its solid steel gleaming in the overcast sunlight. Mat felt an iciness between his shoulder blades. Many travelers along the river thought it some relic from the Age of Legends. What else did you make of a column of steel rising out of the forest, seemingly uninhabited? It was as unnatural and out of place as the twisted red doorways were. Those warped the eyes to look at them.

ðə fɔɹəs fɛl tu stɪl hɪɹ, kwaɪət seɪv fəɹ ðə fʊtstɛps ə ðə θɹi. noʊl wɔkt wɪð ə lɔŋ stæf, tɔlɝ ðən i wɑz. wɛɹ hæɾ i ɡɑɾən ɪt? ɪt hæd ðət smuð, ɔɪld lʊk ʌv wʊd ðət hæd spɛn mɔɹ jɪɹz əz ə wɔkɪŋ stæf ðən ɪɾ ɝɪdʒənəli hæɾ əz ə tʃɹi. noʊl hæɾ ɔlsoʊ pʊɾ ɑn ə dɑɹk blu -  nɪɹli blæk - pɛɹ ə tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə ʃɝt ðət wɑz ʌv ən ɑd, ənnoʊn staɪl. ðə ʃoʊldɝz wɝ stɪfɝ ðən ðə kʌts mæt wɑz fəmɪljɝ wɪð, ən ðə koʊt lɔŋɡɝ, ɡoʊɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn tə noʊlz niz. ɪt bʌɾənd tə ðə weɪst, ðən splɪɾ ət ðə lɛɡz. stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪndid. ði oʊl mæn nɛvɝ wəɾ ænsɝ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊɾ ɪz pæst.

The forest felt too still here, quiet save for the footsteps of the three. Noal walked with a long staff, taller than he was. Where had he gotten it? It had that smooth, oiled look of wood that had spent more years as a walking staff than it originally had as a tree. Noal had also put on a dark blue -  nearly black - pair of trousers and a shirt that was of an odd, unknown style. The shoulders were stiffer than the cuts Mat was familiar with, and the coat longer, going almost all the way down to Noal's knees. It buttoned to the waist, then split at the legs. Strange indeed. The old man never would answer questions about his past.

tɑm hæɾ ɑptɪd fəɹ ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊðɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si hɪm ɪn ðəɾ əɡɛn, ɹæðɝ ðən ðə fɹɪli kɔɹt bɑɹɾ əpæɹəl. ðə pætʃwɝk kloʊk, ðə sɪmpəl ʃɝt ðət taɪɾ ʌp ðə fɹʌnt, ðə taɪt bɹitʃɪz tʌkt ɪndə buts. wən mæt hæɾ æskt əbaʊt ðə tʃɔɪs, tɑm hæd ʃɹʌɡd, seɪɪŋ, "ɪt filz laɪk wʌɾ aɪ ʃəd wɛɹ ɪf aɪm gɑnə si hɝ."

Thom had opted for his gleeman's clothing. It was good to see him in that again, rather than the frilly court bard apparel. The patchwork cloak, the simple shirt that tied up the front, the tight breeches tucked into boots. When Mat had asked about the choice, Thom had shrugged, saying, "It feels like what I should wear if I'm going to see her."

"hɝ" mɛn mɔɪɹeɪn. bʌt wʌt hæd ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz dʌn tə hɝ? ɪt hæd bɪn soʊ lɔŋ, bʌt bɝn ɪm ɪf i wɑz gɑnə lɛɾ ənʌðɝ aʊɝ pæs. hi hæd tʃoʊzən kloʊðɪŋ ə fɔɹəst ɡɹinz ən ɝθi bɹaʊnz, əlɔŋ wɪð ə dip bɹaʊn kloʊk. hi kæɹiɾ ɪz pæk slʌŋ oʊvɝ wʌn ɑɹm ən ɪz æʃhændə-ɹeɪaɪ ɪn ɪz hænd. hi hæd pɹæktəst wɪð ðə nu aɪɝn kaʊntɝweɪɾ ɑn ðə bʌt, ən wɑz plizd.

"Her" meant Moiraine. But what had the snakes and foxes done to her? It had been so long, but burn him if he was going to let another hour pass. He had chosen clothing of forest greens and earthy browns, along with a deep brown cloak. He carried his pack slung over one arm and his ashanda-rei in his hand. He had practiced with the new iron counterweight on the butt, and was pleased.

ði ɛlfɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ðə wɛpən. wɛl, ɪf ðeɪ dɛɹd stæn bɪtwin ɪm ən mɔɪɹeɪn, ðən ðeɪ wəd si wʌɾ i kəd də wɪð ðɛɹ ɡɪft. bɝn hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ wʊd.

The Eelfinn had given him the weapon. Well, if they dared stand between him and Moiraine, then they would see what he could do with their gift. Burn him, but they would.

ðə θɹi mɛn stɛpt ʌp tə ðə taʊɝ. ɪt dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə hæv ə sɪŋɡəl oʊpənɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ ɑn ɪts tu-hʌnʒɹəd-fʊt-tɔl haɪt. nɑɾ ə wɪndoʊ, nɑɾ ə sim, nɑɾ ə skɹætʃ. mæt lʊkt ʌp, filɪŋ dɪsɔɹiɛntɪɾ əz i stɛɹɾ əlɔŋ ɪts ɡlimɪŋ lɛŋθ təwɔɹd ðə dɪstənt ɡɹeɪ skaɪ. dɪd ðə taʊɝ ɹəflɛk tu mʌtʃ laɪt?

The three men stepped up to the tower. It did not appear to have a single opening anywhere on its two-hundred-foot-tall height. Not a window, not a seam, not a scratch. Mat looked up, feeling disoriented as he stared along its gleaming length toward the distant gray sky. Did the tower reflect too much light?

hi ʃʌɾɝəd ən tɝn tə tɑm. mæt ɡeɪv ə sɪŋɡəl nɑd.

He shuddered and turned to Thom. Mat gave a single nod.

hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ oʊnli bɹifli, tɑm slɪɾ ə bɹɑnz naɪf fɹəm ɪts ʃiθ ɑn ɪz bɛlt ən stɛpt oʊvɝ tə sɛt ðə tɪp əɡɛns ðə taʊɝ. hi ɡɹɪmli slɪd ðə naɪf ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl, əbaʊɾ ə pɑm waɪd, pɔɪn daʊn. mɛɾəl skɹeɪpt əɡɛns mɛɾəl, bʌt lɛf noʊ tʃɹeɪl. tɑm fɪnɪʃt baɪ meɪkɪŋ ə weɪvi laɪn θɹu ðə sɛntɝ, əz wʌn dɪɾ ət ðə stɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni ɡeɪm ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz.

Hesitating only briefly, Thom slid a bronze knife from its sheath on his belt and stepped over to set the tip against the tower. He grimly slid the knife in the shape of a triangle, about a palm wide, point down. Metal scraped against metal, but left no trail. Thom finished by making a wavy line through the center, as one did at the start of any game of Snakes and Foxes.

ɔl stʊd saɪlənli. mæt ɡlænst ət θɔɹn. "dɪd jə də ɪt ɹaɪt?"

All stood silently. Mat glanced at Thorn. "Did you do it right?"

"aɪ θɪŋk soʊ," θɔɹn sɛd. "bʌt haʊ də wi noʊ wʌt 'ɹaɪt' ɪz? ðət ɡeɪm əz bɪn pæs daʊn fəɹ - "

"I think so," Thorn said. "But how do we know what 'right' is? That game has been passed down for - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz ə laɪn ə laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə taʊɝ fɹʌnt. mæt dʒʌmp bæk, lɛvəlɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ. ðə ɡloʊɪŋ laɪnz fɔɹmd ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl mætʃɪŋ ðə wʌn ðət θɔɹn hæd dʒɹɔn, ən ðən - kwɪk əz ə sɪŋɡəl biɾ ʌv ə mɔθs wɪŋz - ðə stil ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl vænɪʃt.

He cut off as a line of light appeared on the tower front. Mat jumped back, leveling his spear. The glowing lines formed a triangle matching the one that Thorn had drawn, and then - quick as a single beat of a moth's wings - the steel in the center of the triangle vanished.

noʊl aɪd ðə pɑm-saɪz hoʊl. "ðæts ə tæd smɔl tə ɡɛt θɹu." hi stɛpt ʌp tə ɪɾ ən lʊk θɹu. "nʌθɪŋ bʌt dɑɹknəs ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd."

Noal eyed the palm-sized hole. "That's a tad small to get through." He stepped up to it and looked through. "Nothing but darkness on the other side."

θɔɹn lʊk daʊn ət ðə naɪf. "ɡɛs ðət tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl ɪz æktʃəli  ə dɔɹweɪ. ðæts wʌt jəɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ wən jə stɑɹt ðə ɡeɪm. ʃəɾ aɪ tʃɹaɪ ə bɪɡɝ wʌn?"

Thorn looked down at the knife. "Guess that triangle is actually a doorway. That's what you're drawing when you start the game. Should I try a bigger one?"

"ɡɛs soʊ," mæt sɛd. "ənlɛs ðə ɡoʊləm tɔt jə haʊ tə skwiz θɹu hoʊlz ðə saɪz ʌv ə fɪst."

"Guess so," Mat said. "Unless the gholam taught you how to squeeze through holes the size of a fist."

"noʊ nid tə bi ənplɛzənt," θɔɹn sɛd, juzɪŋ ðə naɪf tə dʒɹɔ ənʌðɝ tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl ɝaʊn ðə fɝst, ðɪs wʌn lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə wɔk θɹu. hi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðə weɪvi laɪn.

"No need to be unpleasant," Thorn said, using the knife to draw another triangle around the first, this one large enough to walk through. He finished with the wavy line.

mæt kaʊntəd. ɪt tʊk sɛvən hɑɹtbits fəɹ ðə laɪnz ʌv waɪt tə əpɪɹ. ðə stil bɪtwin əm feɪɾəd əweɪ, oʊpənɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ kɔɹəɾɝ liɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ. ði ɪnsaɪd lʊk tə bi sɑləd stil.

Mat counted. It took seven heartbeats for the lines of white to appear. The steel between them faded away, opening a triangular corridor leading into the tower. The inside looked to be solid steel.

"laɪt bɝn mi," noʊl wɪspɝd. ðə kɔɹəɾɝ dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪndə dɑɹknəs; ðə sʌnlaɪt sim hɛzɪɾənt tə ɛntɝ ði oʊpənɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli dʒʌst ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə laɪt.

"Light burn me," Noal whispered. The corridor disappeared into darkness; the sunlight seemed hesitant to enter the opening, though it was probably just a trick of the light.

"æn soʊ wi bɪɡɪn ðə ɡeɪm ðət kænɑt bi wʌn," θɔɹn sɛd, slaɪɾɪŋ ðə naɪf bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ.

"And so we begin the game that cannot be won," Thorn said, sliding the knife back into its sheath.

"kɝədʒ tə stʃɹɛŋθən," noʊl wɪspɝd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə læntɝn wɪð ə flɪkɝɪŋ fleɪm. "faɪɝ tə blaɪnd. mjuzɪk tə dæzəl. aɪɝn tə baɪnd."

"Courage to strengthen," Noal whispered, stepping forward, holding up a lantern with a flickering flame. "Fire to blind. Music to dazzle. Iron to bind."

"æn meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," mæt æɾəd. "tə blʌɾi ivən ði ɑdz." hi stɛp θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ.

"And Matrim Cauthon," Mat added. "To bloody even the odds." He stepped through the doorway.

laɪt flæʃt, bɹɪljənt waɪt, blaɪndɪŋ. hi kɝst, skwizɪŋ, hɪz aɪz ʃʌɾ ən loʊɝɪŋ ɪz æsbændʒɹeɪ ɪn wʌɾ i hoʊpt wɑz ə θɹɛɾənɪŋ pɑstʃɝ. hi blɪŋkt ən ðə waɪtnəs feɪɾəd. hi wɑz ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ə waɪd ɹum wɪð ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ oʊpənɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, fɹistændɪŋ, wɪð ðə pɔɪn daʊn ət ðə flɔɹ. ɪt wɑz pjʊɹ blæk, meɪɾ ə twɪstɪŋ kɔɹdz ðəɾ ɪn səm pleɪsəz simd mɛɾəl ən ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz simd wʊd.

Light flashed, brilliant white, blinding. He cursed, squeezing, his eyes shut and lowering his asbandarei in what he hoped was a threatening posture. He blinked and the whiteness faded. He was in the center of a wide room with a triangular opening behind him, freestanding, with the point down at the floor. It was pure black, made of twisting cords that in some places seemed metal and in other places seemed wood.

ðə ɹum wɑz blæk əz wɛl, ʃeɪp laɪk ən ɔf-kɪltɝ skwɛɹ. ɹɪpəlɪŋ waɪt stim pɔɹɾ ʌp fɹəm hoʊlz əɾ ɔl fɔɹ kɔɹnɝz; ðət mɪst ɡloʊd wɪð ə waɪt laɪt. ðəɹ wɝ fɔɹ hɔlweɪz ɪkstɛndɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹum, wʌn ɪn itʃ dɝɛkʃən.

The room was black as well, shaped like an off-kilter square. Rippling white steam poured up from holes at all four corners; that mist glowed with a white light. There were four hallways extending from the room, one in each direction.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli skwɛɹ. itʃ saɪd wɑz ə slaɪtli dɪfɹən lɛŋθ ðən ði ʌðɝz, meɪkɪŋ fəɹ ən ɑd miɾɪŋ ʌv æŋɡəlz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz. ən ðət stim! ɪt ɡeɪv ɔf ə sʌlfɝəs stɛntʃ ðət meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə bɹið θɹu hɪz maʊð. ði ɑnɪks-kʌlɝd wɔlz wɝ nɑt stoʊn, bʌt wɝ ə səm ɹɪflɛktɪv mətɪɹiəl, laɪk ðə skeɪlz ʌv ɪnɔɹməs fɪʃ. ðə stim kəlɛktəɾ ət ðə silɪŋ, ɡloʊɪŋ feɪnli wɪð ə sɑf laɪt.

The chamber was not exactly square. Each side was a slightly different length than the others, making for an odd meeting of angles at the corners. And that steam! It gave off a sulphurous stench that made him want to breathe through his mouth. The onyx-colored walls were not stone, but were of some reflective material, like the scales of enormous fish. The steam collected at the ceiling, glowing faintly with a soft light.

bɝn hɪm! ðɪs wɑz nɑt laɪk ðə fɝs pleɪs i hæd vɪzəɾəd, wɪð ɪts twɪstɪŋ kɔɪlz ən sɝkjəlɝ dɔɹweɪz, bʌt nɔɹ wɑz ɪt laɪk ðə sɛkənd wʌn, wɪð ðə stɑɹ-ʃeɪpt ɹumz ən laɪnz ə jɛloʊ laɪt!

Burn him! This was not like the first place he had visited, with its twisting coils and circular doorways, but nor was it like the second one, with the star-shaped rooms and lines of yellow light!

wɛɹ wɑz hi? wʌt hæɾ i ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf ɪntu? hi tɝn əbaʊt, nɝvəs.

Where was he? What had he gotten himself into? He turned about, nervous.

θɔɹn stʌmbəl θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ, blɪŋkɪŋ, deɪzd. mæt dʒɹɑpt ɪz pæk ən kɑt ðə ɡlimən baɪ wʌn ɑɹm. noʊl keɪm nɛkst. ðə boʊni mæn kɛpt ɪz fʊɾɪŋ, bʌt wɑz ɑbviəsli blaɪndɪd, hɪz læntɝn hɛl fɔɹwɝd dɪfɛnsɪvli.

Thorn stumbled through the doorway, blinking, dazed. Mat dropped his pack and caught the gleeman by one arm. Noal came next. The bony man kept his footing, but was obviously blinded, his lantern held forward defensively.

ðə tu ʌðɝz blɪŋkt, tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ fɹəm noʊlz aɪz, bʌt ðeɪ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡɑt ðɛɹ bɛɹɪŋz ən ɡlænst əbaʊt. ðə ɹum, laɪk ðə hɔlweɪz ɪkstɛndɪŋ ɪn ɔl fɔɹ dɝɛkʃənz, wɑz ɛmpti.

The two others blinked, tears streaming from Noal's eyes, but they eventually got their bearings and glanced about. The room, like the hallways extending in all four directions, was empty.

"ðɪs dʌzn lʊk laɪk wʌt jə dɪskɹaɪbd, mæt," θɔɹn sɛd. hɪz vɔɪs ɛkoʊd feɪnli, ðoʊ ðə saʊnz simd ɪɹəli wɔɹpt. ɔlmoʊs laɪk wɪspɝz θɹoʊn bæk ət ðɛm. ɪt meɪd ðə hɛɹ ɑn mæts nɛk ɹaɪz.

"This doesn't look like what you described, Mat," Thorn said. His voice echoed faintly, though the sounds seemed eerily warped. Almost like whispers thrown back at them. It made the hair on Mat's neck rise.

"aɪ noʊ," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ə tɔɹtʃ fɹəm ɪz pæk. "ðɪs pleɪs dʌzn meɪks sɛns. ðə stɔɹiz əɡɹi əbaʊt ðæt, ət list. hɪɹ, laɪt ðɪs, noʊl."

"I know," Mat said, pulling a torch from his pack. "This place doesn't makes sense. The stories agree about that, at least. Here, light this, Noal."

θɔɹn ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə tɔɹtʃ ə hɪz oʊn ən boʊθ lɪt fɹəm noʊlz læntɝn. ðeɪ hæd stʃɹaɪkɝz fɹəm ɑlʌdʒɹə, bʌt mæt wɑntəd tə seɪv ðoʊz. hi hæd bɪn hæf-əfɹeɪd ðəɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, fleɪmz wəd ɡoʊ aʊt wʌns lɪt.

Thorn got out a torch of his own and both lit from Noal's lantern. They had strikers from Aludra, but Mat wanted to save those. He had been half-afraid that in the tower, flames would go out once lit.

bʌt ðə laɪts bɝn stɛɾi ən tʃɹu. ðət hɑɹɾənd ɪm sʌmwʌt.

But the lights burned steady and true. That heartened him somewhat.

"soʊ wɛɹ ɑɹ ðeɪ?" θɔɹn æskt, wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə pɝɪməɾɝ ə ðə blæk ɹum.

"So where are they?" Thorn asked, walking around the perimeter of the black room.

"ðeɪɹ nɛvɝ hɪɹ wən jə kʌm θɹu," mæt sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ɪz oʊn tɔɹtʃ ən ɪnspɛktɪŋ ə wɔl. wɑz ðət ɹaɪɾɪŋ, kɑɹvd ɪndə ðə nɑt-stoʊn? ði ʌnfəmɪljɝ skɹɪpt wɑz soʊ faɪn ən dɛləkəɾ i kəd bɛɹli si ɪt. "bʌt wɑtʃ jɝsɛlf. ðeɪ kən əpɪɹ bɪhaɪn ju, fæstɝ ðən ən ɪnkipɝ u hɝd kɔɪnz klɪŋk ɪn jəɹ paʊtʃ."

"They're never here when you come through," Mat said, holding up his own torch and inspecting a wall. Was that writing, carved into the not-stone? The unfamiliar script was so fine and delicate he could barely see it. "But watch yourself. They can appear behind you, faster than an innkeeper who heard coins clink in your pouch."

noʊl ɪnspɛktɪd ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ oʊpənɪŋ ðeɪ hæd kʌm θɹu. "du jə səpoʊz wi kən juz ðɪs tə ɡɛt bæk?" ɪt ɹɪzɛmbəl ðə stoʊn tɛɹæŋɡɹil mæt hæd stɛp θɹu bɪfɔɹ. dʒʌst ə dɪfɹənt ʃeɪp.

Noal inspected the triangular opening they had come through. "Do you suppose we can use this to get back?" It resembled the stone ter'angreal Mat had stepped through before. Just a different shape.

"aɪ hoʊp soʊ," mæt sɛd."

"I hope so," Mat said."

"meɪbi wi ʃəd tʃɹaɪ," noʊl sɛd.

"Maybe we should try," Noal said.

mæt nɑɾəd tə hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ sɛpɝeɪɾəd, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nid tə noʊ ɪf ðɪs wɑz ə weɪ bæk əɹ nɑt. noʊl lʊk dɪtɝmən ən stɛp θɹu. hi vænɪʃt.

Mat nodded to him. He did not like being separated, but they did need to know if this was a way back or not. Noal looked determined and stepped through. He vanished.

mæt hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, bʌt ði eɪdʒɪd mæn dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn. wɑz ɪɾ ə tʃɹɪk? hæd ðɪs dɔɹweɪ bɪn pleɪs hɪɹ tə -  noʊl stʌmbəl bæk ɪndə ðə ɹum θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ. θɔɹn sɛɾ ɪz tɔɹtʃ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən dæʃt oʊvɝ tə hɛlp. noʊl ɹəkʌvɝd mɔɹ kwɪkli ðɪs taɪm, blɪŋkɪŋ əweɪ ðə blaɪndnəs. "ɪt sil mi aʊt,"

Mat held his breath for a long moment, but the aged man did not return. Was it a trick? Had this doorway been placed here to -  Noal stumbled back into the room through the opening. Thorn set his torch on the floor and dashed over to help. Noal recovered more quickly this time, blinking away the blindness. "It sealed me out,"

hi ɪkspleɪnd. "aɪ hæd tə dʒɹɔ ənʌðɝ tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl tə ɡɛt bæk ɪn."

he explained. "I had to draw another triangle to get back in."

"æt list wi noʊ wiv ɡɑɾ ə minz ʌv ɪskeɪp," θɔɹn sɛd.

"At least we know we've got a means of escape," Thorn said.

əsumɪŋ ðoʊz blʌɾi æɛlfɪn əɹ ɛlfɪn doʊn muv ɪt, mæt θɔt, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɪz pɹiviəs vɪzət, ðə wʌn ðət hæɾ ɛndəd wɪð ɪm biɪŋ hæŋd. ðət taɪm, ðə ɹumz ən kɔɹɪɾɝz hæd ʃɪftəd mɪstɪɹiəsli, ɪn toʊɾəl dɪfaɪəns ʌv wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt.

Assuming those bloody Aelfinn or Eelfinn don't move it, Mat thought, remembering his previous visit, the one that had ended with him being hanged. That time, the rooms and corridors had shifted mysteriously, in total defiance of what was right.

"wɪl jə lʊk ət ðæt?" θɔɹn sɛd.

"Will you look at that?" Thorn said.

mæt loʊɝɾ ɪz spɪɹ ən noʊl hæɾ ən aɪɝn ʃɔɹtsɔɝɾ ɪn ɪz hæn ɪn ə moʊmənt. θɔɹn wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ɪz tɔɹtʃ, wɪtʃ bɝn fɪtfəli wɛɹ i hæd sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə ɡloʊɪŋ stim vɛns.

Mat lowered his spear and Noal had an iron shortsword in his hand in a moment. Thorn was pointing at his torch, which burned fitfully where he had set it on the floor beside one of the glowing steam vents.

ðə waɪt stim pʊʃt əweɪ fɹəm ðə fleɪmz, laɪk ɪt wɑz biɪŋ bloʊn baɪ ə bɹiz. oʊnli, noʊ bɹiz ɛvɝ meɪd stim muv soʊ ənnətʃɝəli. ɪt kɝvd ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ ɪn ə lup. θɔɹn stɛpt oʊvɝ ən pɪkt ʌp ðə tɔɹtʃ. hi muvd ɪt təwɔɹd ðə kɑləm ə stim, ən ɪt baʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. θɔɹn ɹæm ðə tɔɹtʃ dɝɛkli ɪndə ðə stimz pæθ, ən ðə stim splɪt, ɡoʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə fleɪm ən mɛldɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɪndə ə sɪŋɡəl stʃɹim əɡɛn əbʌv.

The white steam pushed away from the flames, like it was being blown by a breeze. Only, no breeze ever made steam move so unnaturally. It curved around the fire in a loop. Thorn stepped over and picked up the torch. He moved it toward the column of steam, and it bowed out of the way. Thorn rammed the torch directly into the steam's path, and the steam split, going around the flame and melding together into a single stream again above.

θɔɹn ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝz.

Thorn glanced at the others.

"doʊn æsk mi," mæt sɛd, skaʊlɪŋ. "aɪ sɛd ðɪs pleɪs dʌzn meɪk sɛns. ɪf ðæts ði ɑɾəst θɪŋ wi si hɪɹ, əl bi ə mʊɹændiənz mʌstæʃ. kʌm ɑn."

"Don't ask me," Mat said, scowling. "I said this place doesn't make sense. If that's the oddest thing we see here, I'll be a Murandian's mustache. Come on."

mæt pɪkt wʌn ə ðə hɔlweɪz ən bɪɡæn tə wɔk daʊn ɪt. ði ʌðɝ tu hɝid tə kætʃ ʌp. ðə stim ɡloʊɾ ɑn ðə silɪŋ, beɪðɪŋ ðə blæk hɔlweɪ wɪð ɪts mɪlki laɪt. ðə flɔɹ wɑz meɪɾ ʌv ɪntɝlɑkɪŋ tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ taɪlz ðæt, wʌns əɡɛn, lʊk dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋli laɪk skeɪlz. ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz waɪɾ ən lɔŋ, ði ʌðɝ ɛn dɪstən ən dɑɹk.

Mat picked one of the hallways and began to walk down it. The other two hurried to catch up. The steam glowed on the ceiling, bathing the black hallway with its milky light. The floor was made of interlocking triangular tiles that, once again, looked discomfortingly like scales. The corridor was wide and long, the other end distant and dark.

"tə θɪŋk," noʊl sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ɪz læntɝn, "ɔl ə ðɪs hɪɾən ɪn ðət sɪŋɡəl taʊɝ."

"To think," Noal said, holding up his lantern, "all of this hidden in that single tower."

"aɪ daʊt wɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɛnimɔɹ," mæt sɛd. ʌp əhɛd, hi kəd si ə slaɪs aʊɾ ə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, ə kaɪndə wɪndoʊ. ɪt wɑz sɛɾ ʌp ə lɪɾəl tu haɪ ʌp tə fil nætʃɹəl.

"I doubt we're in the tower anymore," Mat said. Up ahead, he could see a slice out of the side of the wall, a kind of window. It was set up a little too high up to feel natural.

"ðɛn wɛɹ. . . ." noʊl tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə wɪndoʊ, wɪtʃ wɑz ən ɔf-sɛntɝ skwɛɹ.

"Then where. . . ." Noal trailed off as they reached the window, which was an off-center square.

θɹu ɪt, ðeɪ kəd lʊk aʊɾ əɾ ən ənnætʃɹəl lændskeɪp. ðeɪ wɝ ʌp sɛvɹəl flɔɹz ɪn səm kaɪndə spaɪɹ, bʌt ðət sɝɾənli wɑz nɑɾ ændɝ aʊtsaɪd.

Through it, they could look out at an unnatural landscape. They were up several floors in some kind of spire, but that certainly was not Andor outside.

ðə wɪndoʊ lʊkt aʊɾ oʊvɝ ə kænəpi ʌv dɛns vɛdʒəteɪʃən ðət wɑz tu jɛloʊ. mæt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə wɪspi tʃɹiz wɪð ə dʒɹupɪŋ əmbɹɛlə ʌv bɹæntʃəz ət ðə tɑp, ðoʊ bɪfɔɹ i hæd sin əm fɹəm bɪloʊ. ðə fɝnlaɪk tʃɹiz wɪð ðɛɹ spɹɛɾɪŋ fænz ə livz wɝ fəmɪljɝ əz wɛl, ðoʊ ðoʊz hæd dip blæk fɹuts hæŋɪŋ fɹəm əm naʊ. ðə lɑɹdʒ fɹuts kɑz ðə livz tə dʒɹup.

The window looked out over a canopy of dense vegetation that was too yellow. Mat recognized the wispy trees with a drooping umbrella of branches at the top, though before he had seen them from below. The fernlike trees with their spreading fans of leaves were familiar as well, though those had deep black fruits hanging from them now. The large fruits caused the leaves to droop.

"mɝsi ʌv ðə wɪnoʊɝ," noʊl wɪspɝd, ə fɹeɪz mæt hæd nɛvɝ hɝd bɪfɔɹ.

"Mercy of the Winnower," Noal whispered, a phrase Mat had never heard before.

noʊl hæd ɹizən tə bi əstɑnɪʃt; mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ət ðət fɔɹəs fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ðə twɪstəd dɔɹweɪ hæd nɑt bɹɔɾ ɪm tə ənʌðɝ pleɪs, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ wɝld ɪntaɪɝli.

Noal had reason to be astonished; Mat remembered looking out at that forest for the first time, realizing that the twisted doorway had not brought him to another place, but another world entirely.

mæt lʊk tə ðə saɪd. kəɾ i si ðə θɹi spaɪɹz i hæd noʊɾəd ɑn ɪz fɝs vɪzət? ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi əbaʊt, ðoʊ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, ðə vɛɹi nɛkst wɪndoʊ ðeɪ pæs kəd ʃoʊ ə dɪfɹən sin. ðeɪ kʊd. . . .

Mat looked to the side. Could he see the three spires he had noted on his first visit? They did not seem to be about, though in this place, the very next window they passed could show a different scene. They could. . . .

hi pɔzd, ðən ɡlænst ʃɑɹpli θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ. hi kəd meɪk aʊɾ ə spaɪɹ tə ðə lɛft. ən ðən i nu. hi wɑz ɪn wʌn ə ðə spaɪɹz i hæd sin ɪn ðə dɪstəns dʊɹɪŋ ɪz fɝs vɪzət.

He paused, then glanced sharply through the window. He could make out a spire to the left. And then he knew. He was in one of the spires he had seen in the distance during his first visit.

hi staɪfəld ə ʃɪvɝ ən tɝn əweɪ. ət list i nu fəɹ sɝɾən i wɑz ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs. dɪd ðət min ðət ðə wɝlz ə ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn wɝ ðə seɪm? hi hoʊp soʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd fɔlən θɹu ðə sɛkən ə ðə twɪstəd ɹɛd dɔɹweɪz, wɪtʃ mɛnt ʃi hæd moʊs laɪkli bɪn teɪkən baɪ ði ɛlfɪn, ðə fɑksəz.

He stifled a shiver and turned away. At least he knew for certain he was in the same place. Did that mean that the worlds of the Aelfinn and the Eelfinn were the same? He hoped so. Moiraine had fallen through the second of the twisted red doorways, which meant she had most likely been taken by the Eelfinn, the foxes.

ðeɪ wɝ ðə wʌnz u hæd hæŋ mæt; ðə sneɪks, ət list, hæɾ oʊnli tɔst ɪm aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ ɹɛlm wɪθaʊɾ ɛni jusfəl ænsɝz. hi bɔɹ əm ə ɡɹʌdʒ, bʌt ðə fɑksəz . . . ðeɪ hæd ɹəfjuz tə ænsɝ ɪz kwɛstʃənz, ən hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ðiz blʌɾi mɛmɹiz ɪnstɛd!

They were the ones who had hanged Mat; the snakes, at least, had only tossed him out of their realm without any useful answers. He bore them a grudge, but the foxes . . . they had refused to answer his questions, and had given him these bloody memories instead!

mæt ən ði ʌðɝz kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ, ðɛɹ fʊtstɛps ɛkoʊɪŋ əɡɛns ðə flɔɹɪŋ. sun, mæt bɪɡæn tə ɡɛt ðə sɛns ðəɾ i wɑz biɪŋ wɑtʃt. hi hæd fɛlt ɪt bɪfɔɹ, ɑn ɪz ʌðɝ vɪzəts. hi tɝn tə ðə saɪd, ən kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə feɪn moʊʃən fɑɹ bɪhaɪnd.

Mat and the others continued down the hallway, their footsteps echoing against the flooring. Soon, Mat began to get the sense that he was being watched. He had felt it before, on his other visits. He turned to the side, and caught a glimpse of faint motion far behind.

hi spʌn, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə tɔs ɪz tɔɹtʃ əsaɪɾ ən faɪt wɪð ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, bʌt sɔ nʌθɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ tu fɹoʊz, lʊkɪŋ əbaʊt, æŋkʃəs. mæt kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn ʃipɪʃli, ðoʊ hi fɛlt lɛs soʊ æftɝ θɔɹn dɪd ðə seɪm θɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ. θɔɹn wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə θɹoʊ ə naɪf əɾ ə dɑɹkən pætʃ ə ðə wɔl.

He spun, preparing to toss his torch aside and fight with his ashandarei, but saw nothing. The other two froze, looking about, anxious. Mat continued on sheepishly, though he felt less so after Thorn did the same thing a short time later. Thorn went so far as to throw a knife at a darkened patch of the wall.

ði aɪɝn wɛpən klæŋkt əɡɛns ðə sɝfəs. ðə dʌl ɹɪŋ ɛkoʊd fəɹ fɑɹ tu lɔŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ.

The iron weapon clanked against the surface. The dull ring echoed for far too long in the hallway.

"sɑɹi," θɔɹn sɛd.

"Sorry," Thorn said.

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd.

"It's all right," Mat said.

"ðeɪɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ʌs, ɑɹən ðeɪ?" noʊl æskt. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz sɑft feɪnli nɝvəs. laɪt! mæt fɛlt əz ɪf i wɑz gɑnə dʒʌmp aʊɾ ə hɪz skɪn ən ɹʌn əweɪ, livɪŋ ɪt bɪhaɪnd. kəmpɛɹd tə ðæt, noʊl sim stɛɾi.

"They're watching us, aren't they?" Noal asked. His voice was soft faintly nervous. Light! Mat felt as if he was going to jump out of his skin and run away, leaving it behind. Compared to that, Noal seemed steady.

"aɪ səspɛk ðeɪ ɑɹ, ət ðæt," mæt sɛd.

"I suspect they are, at that," Mat said.

wɪðɪn ə fju moʊməns, ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði ɛn ə ðə tu-lɔŋ hɔlweɪ hɪɹ, ðeɪ ɛntɝɾ ə tʃeɪmbɝ ðət wɑz aɪdɛntɪkəl tə ðə fɝst, seɪv ɪt hæd noʊ dɔɹweɪ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ. ɪt splɪɾ ɔf ɪn fɔɹ dɝɛkʃənz, itʃ kɔɹəɾɝ dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɪstən dɑɹknəs.

Within a few moments, they reached the end of the too-long hallway Here, they entered a chamber that was identical to the first, save it had no doorway in the center. It split off in four directions, each corridor disappearing into the distant darkness.

ðeɪ pɪkt ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən, mɛmɝaɪzɪŋ ðə pæθ ðeɪ wɝ teɪkɪŋ, ənsin aɪz skɹætʃɪŋ ət ðɛɹ bæks. hɪz fʊtstɛps ɡɹu mɔɹ hɝiɾ əz ðeɪ tʃɹævɝs ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə hɔlweɪ ən ɛntɝɾ ənʌðɝ tʃeɪmbɝ. ɪt wɑz ɪɡzækli laɪk ðə pɹiviəs wʌn.

They picked another direction, memorizing the path they were taking, unseen eyes scratching at their backs. His footsteps grew more hurried as they traversed the length of the hallway and entered another chamber. It was exactly like the previous one.

"izi tə bi dɪsɔɹiɛntɪɾ ɪn ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs," noʊl sɛd. hi oʊpən ɪz pæk ən ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ ən ə tʃɑɹkoʊl pɛnsəl. hi meɪd θɹi dɑts ɑn ɪz peɪpɝ, ðən kənɛktəɾ əm baɪ laɪnz, ɹɛpɹɪzɛntɪŋ ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ən ɹumz ðeɪd ɡɔn θɹu. "ɪts ɔl ə mæɾɝ ə kipɪŋ ə ɡʊd mæp. ə ɡʊd mæp kən min laɪf əɹ dɛθ; jə kən tʃɹʌs mi ɑn ðæt."

"Easy to be disoriented in a place like this," Noal said. He opened his pack and got out a sheet of paper and a charcoal pencil. He made three dots on his paper, then connected them by lines, representing the corridors and rooms they'd gone through. "It's all a matter of keeping a good map. A good map can mean life or death; you can trust me on that."

mæt tɝn ɝaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm wɑntəd tə kip ɡoʊɪŋ, nɑt lʊk bækwɝd, bʌɾ i hæd tə noʊ. "kʌm ɑn," hi sɛd, ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm.

Mat turned around, looking back the way they had come. Part of him wanted to keep going, not look backward, but he had to know. "Come on," he said, going back the way they had come.

θɔɹn ən noʊl ʃɛɹd lʊks, bʌt wʌns əɡɛn hɝid tə kætʃ ʌp. ɪt tʊk əm ə ɡʊd hæf-aʊɝ tə ɹitʃɹeɪs ðɛɹ stɛps bæk tə ðə fɝs tʃeɪmbɝ, ðə wʌn ðət ʃəd kənteɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. ðeɪ faʊn ɪɾ ɛmpti. ðoʊz kɑləmz ə stim ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝz. ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ tu ɹumz, tu.

Thorn and Noal shared looks, but once again hurried to catch up. It took them a good half-hour to retrace their steps back to the first chamber, the one that should contain the doorway. They found it empty. Those columns of steam rose from the corners. They had in the other two rooms, too.

"ɪmpɑsəbəl!" noʊl sɛd. "wi ɹitʃɹeɪst əɹ stɛps pɝfəkli! ðə weɪ aʊt ʃəd bi hɪɹ."

"Impossible!" Noal said. "We retraced our steps perfectly! The way out should be here."

ɪn ðə dɪstəns - feɪn ən ɔlmoʊst ɪnɔɾəbəl - mæt hɝd læftɝ. ə hɪsɪŋ, deɪnʒɝəs læftɝ.

In the distance - faint and almost inaudible - Mat heard laughter. A hissing, dangerous laughter.

məlɪʃəs.

Malicious.

mæts skɪn ɡɹu aɪsi. "θɔɹn," hi sɛd, "ju ɛvɝ hɪɹ ə stɔɹi əbaʊt bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ ən əɹ vɪzət tə ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ?"

Mat's skin grew icy. "Thorn," he said, "you ever hear a story about Birgitte Silverbow and her visit to the Tower of Ghenjei?"

"bɝdʒɪt?" tɑm æskt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ɪz ɪnspɛkʃən - wɪð noʊl - ʌv ðə flɔɹ. ðeɪ sim kənvɪns ðət ðə dɔɹweɪ mʌst əv bɪn pʊl daʊn ɪndə səm hɪɾən tʃɹæpdɔɹ. "noʊ, kæn seɪ ðəɾ aɪ hæv.

"Birgitte?" Thom asked, looking up from his inspection - with Noal - of the floor. They seemed convinced that the doorway must have been pulled down into some hidden trapdoor. "No, can't say that I have.

"wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ə stɔɹi ʌv ə wʊmən tʃɹæp fəɹ tu mʌnθs ɪn ə meɪz ə kɔɹɪɾɝz ɪnsaɪɾ ə fɔɹtʃɹəs?"

"What about a story of a woman trapped for two months in a maze of corridors inside a fortress?"

"tu mʌnθs?" tɑm sɛd. "wɛl, noʊ. bʌt ðɛɹz ðə teɪl ʌv ɛlməɑɹə ən ðə ʃæɾoʊaɪz. ʃi spɛn ə hʌnʒɹəd deɪz wɑndɝɪŋ ɪn ə meɪz, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ði ɪnfəməs hilɪŋ spɹɪŋ ə sʌn tə seɪv əɹ lʌvɝz laɪf."

"Two months?" Thom said. "Well, no. But there's the tale of Elmiara and the Shadoweyes. She spent a hundred days wandering in a maze, looking for the infamous healing spring of Sund to save her lover's life."

ðət wɑz pɹɑbli ɪt. ðə stɔɹi hæd sɝvaɪvd; ɪt hæd tʃeɪnʒd fɔɹmz, ðə weɪ soʊ mɛni ʌv əm dɪd.

That was probably it. The story had survived; it had changed forms, the way so many of them did.

"ʃi dɪdnt ɡɛɾ aʊt, dɪd ʃi?"

"She didn't get out, did she?"

"noʊ. ʃi daɪɾ ət ði ɛnd, oʊnli tu stɛps əweɪ fɹəm ðə faʊntən, bʌt sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ɪt baɪ ə wɔl.

"No. She died at the end, only two steps away from the fountain, but separated from it by a wall.

ʃi kəd hɪɹ ɪt bʌbəlɪŋ; ɪt wɑz ðə læst saʊnd ʃi hɝd bɪfɔɹ daɪɪŋ fɹəm θɝst." hi ɡlænst əbaʊɾ ənkʌmftəbli, əz ɪf ənsɝɾən i wɑntəd tə bi ʃɛɹɪŋ sətʃ ə stɔɹi ɪn ðɪs pleɪs.

She could hear it bubbling; it was the last sound she heard before dying from thirst." He glanced about uncomfortably, as if uncertain he wanted to be sharing such a story in this place.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, wɝid. bɝn hɪm, bʌɾ i heɪɾəd ðiz fɑksəz. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ tə -  "ju hæv bɹoʊkən ðə bɑɹɡən," ə sɑf vɔɪs sɛd.

Mat shook his head, worried. Burn him, but he hated these foxes. There had to be a way to -  "You have broken the bargain," a soft voice said.

mæt spʌn ən ði ʌðɝ tu kɝst, stændɪŋ ʌp, hænz ɑn wɛpənz. ə fɪɡjɝ stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə kɹitʃɝz mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd, pɝhæps ði ɪɡzæk seɪm wʌn u hæd mɛɾ ɪm læs taɪm. ʃɔɹt, bɹaɪt ɹɛd hɛɹ spɹaʊɾəd fɹəm ðə kɹitʃɝz peɪl skælp. ə pɛɹ ʌv ɪɹz klʌŋ tə ðə hɛd, slaɪtli pɔɪntəɾ ət ðə tɪps. ðə fɪɡjɝ wɑz wɪləwi ən tɔl, ðə ʃoʊldɝz dɪspɹəpɔɹʃənətli waɪd fəɹ ðə weɪst, ən ɪt wɔɹ peɪl lɛðɝ stʃɹæps kɹɔs ðə tʃɛst - mæt stɪl dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt ðoʊz maɪɾ əv bɪn meɪɾ ʌv - ən ə lɔŋ blæk kɪl bɪloʊ.

Mat spun and the other two cursed, standing up, hands on weapons. A figure stood in the hallway behind them. It was one of the creatures Mat remembered, perhaps the exact same one who had met him last time. Short, bright red hair sprouted from the creature's pale scalp. A pair of ears clung to the head, slightly pointed at the tips. The figure was willowy and tall, the shoulders disproportionately wide for the waist, and it wore pale leather straps crossed the chest - Mat still did not want to think about what those might have been made of - and a long black kilt below.

ɪt wɑz ðə feɪs ðət wɑz moʊs dɪstɪŋktɪv. lɑɹdʒ, ənnætʃɹəl aɪz, peɪl wɪð ə ʃeɪɾ ʌv aɪɹəs ɪn ðə sɛntɝ. ə nɛɹoʊ dʒɔ ən æŋɡjəlɝ fitʃɝz. laɪk ə fɑks. wʌn ə ði ɛlfɪn, mæstɝz ə ðɪs ɹɛlm.

It was the face that was most distinctive. Large, unnatural eyes, pale with a shade of iris in the center. A narrow jaw and angular features. Like a fox. One of the Eelfinn, masters of this realm.

ɪt hæd kʌm tə pleɪ wɪð ðə maɪs.

It had come to play with the mice.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ bɑɹɡən ðɪs weɪ," mæt sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðə nɝvəsnəs fɹəm ɪz vɔɪs. "wi kən blʌɾi bɹɪŋ wʌt wi wɑnt."

"There is no bargain this way," Mat said, trying to keep the nervousness from his voice. "We can bloody bring what we want."

"hævɪŋ noʊ bɑɹɡən ɪz deɪnʒɝəs," ði ɛlfɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə smuð vɔɪs. "fɔɹ ju. fɔɹtʃənətli, aɪ kən teɪk jə wɛɹ jə dɪzaɪɝ."

"Having no bargain is dangerous," the Eelfinn said in a smooth voice. "For you. Fortunately, I can take you where you desire."

"wɛl, ðɛn," mæt sɛd. "du ɪt."

"Well, then," Mat said. "Do it."

"liv jəɹ aɪɝn," ði ɛlfɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ ɪmpləməns ə mjuzɪk. jəɹ faɪɝ."

"Leave your iron," the Eelfinn said. "Your implements of music. Your fire."

"nɛvɝ," mæt sɛd.

"Never," Mat said.

ði ɛlfɪn blɪŋk lɑɹdʒ aɪz. sloʊli, dɪlɪbɝətli. ɪt stɛp fɔɹwɝd, fʊtstɛps sɑft. mæt ɹeɪzd ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, bʌt ði ɛlfɪn meɪd noʊ dɝɛkli θɹɛɾənɪŋ muvz. ɪt ɡlaɪɾɪd ɝaʊn ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm, spikɪŋ sɔfli.

The Eelfinn blinked large eyes. Slowly, deliberately. It stepped forward, footsteps soft. Mat raised his ashandarei, but the Eelfinn made no directly threatening moves. It glided around the three of them, speaking softly.

"kʌm naʊ," ɪt sɛd. "kæn wi nɑt spik wɪð səvɪləɾi? juv kʌm tə əɹ ɹɛlm sikɪŋ. wɪv paʊɝ tə ɡɹænt wʌt jə wɪʃ, wʌt jə nid. waɪ nɑt ʃoʊ ɡʊd feɪθ? liv bɪhaɪn jəɹ ɪmpləməns ə faɪɝ. ðoʊz oʊnli, ən aɪ pɹɑməs tə lid jə fəɹ ə taɪm."

"Come now," it said. "Can we not speak with civility? You have come to our realm seeking. We have power to grant what you wish, what you need. Why not show good faith? Leave behind your implements of fire. Those only, and I promise to lead you for a time."

ɪts vɔɪs wɑz hɪpnɑɾɪk, suðɪŋ. ɪt dɪd meɪk sɛns. wʌt nid hæd ðeɪ ʌv faɪɝ? ɪt wɑz laɪɾ ɪnʌf wɪð ðət mɪst. ɪt . . .

Its voice was hypnotic, soothing. It did make sense. What need had they of fire? It was light enough with that mist. It . . .

"θɔɹn," mæt sɛd. "mjuzɪk."

"Thorn," Mat said. "Music."

"wʌt?" θɔɹn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ə lɪɾəl bɪt.

"What?" Thorn said, shaking a little bit.

"pleɪ ɛniθɪŋ. ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ wʌt."

"Play anything. It doesn't matter what."

θɔɹn tʊk aʊɾ ɪz flut, ən ði ɛlfɪn nɛɹoʊɾ ɪts aɪz. θɔɹn bɪɡæn pleɪɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə fəmɪljɝ sɔŋ, "ðə wɪn ðət ʃeɪks ðə wɪloʊz" mæt hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə suð ði ɛlfɪn, meɪbi pʊɾ ɪɾ ɔf ɡɑɹd. bʌt ðə fəmɪljɝ tun sim tə hɛlp dɪspɛl ðə klaʊɾ ɑn mæts maɪnd.

Thorn took out his flute, and the Eelfinn narrowed its eyes. Thorn began playing. It was a familiar song, "The Wind That Shakes the Willows" Mat had intended to soothe the Eelfinn, maybe put it off guard. But the familiar tune seemed to help dispel the cloud on Mat's mind.

"ðɪs ɪzənt niɾəd," ði ɛlfɪn sɛd, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət θɔɹn.

"This isn't needed," the Eelfinn said, glaring at Thorn.

"jɛs ɪɾ ɪz," mæt sɛd. "ænd wɝ nɑt blʌɾi livɪŋ əɹ faɪɝ. nɑɾ ənlɛs jə pɹɑməs tə teɪk əs ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə sɛntʃɹəl tʃeɪmbɝ ən ɡɪv əs bæk mɔɪɹeɪn."

"Yes it is," Mat said. "And we're not bloody leaving our fire. Not unless you promise to take us all the way to the central chamber and give us back Moiraine."

"aɪ kænɑt meɪk ðət bɑɹɡən," ðə kɹitʃɝ sɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə wɔk ɝaʊn ðɛm. mæt tɝn tə fɑloʊ ɪt, nɛvɝ lɛɾɪŋ ɪz bæk tə ðə θɪŋ. "aɪ hæv nɑt ði əθɔɹəɾi."

"I cannot make that bargain," the creature said, continuing to walk around them. Mat turned to follow it, never letting his back to the thing. "I have not the authority."

"bɹɪŋ sʌmwʌn u kæn."

"Bring someone who can."

"ɪmpɑsəbəl," ði ɛlfɪn sɛd. "lɪsən tə mi. faɪɝ ɪzənt niɾəd. əl lid jə hæf ə ðə weɪ tə ðə sɛntʃɹəl tʃeɪmbɝ, ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ə bɑnz, ʃəd jə liv bɪhaɪn ðət tɛɹəbəl faɪɝ. ɪɾ əfɛnz ʌs.

"Impossible," the Eelfinn said. "Listen to me. Fire isn't needed. I will lead you half of the way to the central chamber, the Chamber of Bonds, should you leave behind that terrible fire. It offends us.

wi wɪʃ oʊnli tə mit jəɹ dɪzaɪɝz."

We wish only to meet your desires."

ðə kɹitʃɝ wɑz ɑbviəsli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʌl əm əɡɛn, bʌɾ ɪts keɪɾəns wɑz ɔf, əɾ ɑdz wɪð θɔɹnz pleɪɪŋ. mæt wɑtʃt ɪt, ðən bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə flut pleɪɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv ðə bɛs vɔɪs əmʌŋ ðoʊz i nu, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt tɛɹəbəl iðɝ. ði ɛlfɪn jɔnd, ðən sɛɾəld daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə wɔl ən kloʊzd ɪts aɪz. ɪn moʊməns, ɪt wɑz slipɪŋ.

The creature was obviously trying to lull them again, but its cadence was off, at odds with Thorn's playing. Mat watched it, then began to sing along with the flute playing. He did not have the best voice among those he knew, but he was not terrible either. The Eelfinn yawned, then settled down beside the wall and closed its eyes. In moments, it was sleeping.

θɔɹn loʊɝd ðə flut fɔɹm ɪz lɪps, lʊkɪŋ ɪmpɹɛst.

Thorn lowered the flute form his lips, looking impressed.

"naɪsli dʌn," noʊl wɪspɝd. "aɪ hæd noʊ aɪdiə jə wɝ soʊ fluən ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ."

"Nicely done," Noal whispered. "I had no idea you were so fluent in the Old Tongue."

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən ɹilaɪz ðeɪ hæd bɪn spikɪŋ ɪn ɪt.

Mat hesitated. He had not even realized they had been speaking in it.

"maɪ oʊl tʌŋ ɪz ɹʌsti," noʊl sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn, "bʌɾ aɪ kɑɾ ə lɑɾ ə ðæt. pɹɑbləm ɪz, wi stɪl doʊnt noʊ ðə weɪ θɹu ðɪs pleɪs. haʊ wɪl wi meɪk əɹ weɪ wɪθaʊt wʌn ə ðɛm tə ɡaɪɾ ʌs?"

"My Old Tongue is rusty," Noal said, rubbing his chin, "but I caught a lot of that. Problem is, we still don't know the way through this place. How will we make our way without one of them to guide us?"

hi wɑz ɹaɪt. bɝdʒɪt hæd wɑndɝd fəɹ mʌnθs, nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ ɪf əɹ ɡoʊl wɑz mɪɹli ə fju stɛps əweɪ. ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɛɹ mæt hæd mɛt ði ɛlfɪn liɾɝz . . . ʃi hæd sɛd ðət wʌns jə wɝ ðɛɹ, ðeɪ hæd tə bɑɹɡən wɪð ju. ðət mʌs bi ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ə bɑnz ði ɛlfɪn hæd mɛnʃənd.

He was right. Birgitte had wandered for months, never knowing if her goal was merely a few steps away. The chamber where Mat had met the Eelfinn leaders . . . she had said that once you were there, they had to bargain with you. That must be the Chamber of Bonds the Eelfinn had mentioned.

pʊɹ mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi hæd kʌm θɹu wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd dɔɹweɪz; ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn pɹətɛktəd baɪ wʌtɛvɝ tʃɹiɾi ði ɛlfɪn hæd wɪð ði eɪntʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ðət dɔɹweɪ hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd.

Poor Moiraine. She had come through one of the red doorways; she should have been protected by whatever treaty the Eelfinn had with the ancient Aes Sedai. But that doorway had been destroyed.

noʊ weɪ bæk.

No way back.

wən mæt hæd kʌm ɝɪdʒənəli, ðeɪ hæd pɹeɪzd ɪm əz waɪz fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ tə æsk fəɹ ə liv- teɪkɪŋ. ðoʊ hi ɡɹʌmbəld, stɪl, əbaʊt ði ɛlfɪn nɑɾ ænsɝɪŋ ɪz kwɛstʃənz, hi kəd si ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt ðeɪ dɪd. ði æɛlfɪn wɝ fəɹ kwɛstʃənz; ði ɛlfɪn ɡɹæntəd ɹɪkwɛsts. bʌt ðeɪ twɪstəd ðoʊz ɹɪkwɛsts, ən tʊk wʌtɛvɝ pɹaɪs ðeɪ wɑntəd. mæt hæɾ ənwɪɾɪŋli æsk fəɹ ɪz mɛmɹi fɪld, fəɹ ə weɪ tə bi fɹi ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ.

When Mat had come originally, they had praised him as wise for thinking to ask for a leave- taking. Though he grumbled, still, about the Eelfinn not answering his questions, he could see that was not what they did. The Aelfinn were for questions; the Eelfinn granted requests. But they twisted those requests, and took whatever price they wanted. Mat had unwittingly asked for his memory filled, for a way to be free of the Aes Sedai, and a way out of the Tower.

ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt noʊn ðɪs, ən hæd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ pæsədʒ aʊɾ əz i hæd dʌn ... əɹ ɪf ʃi hæɾ æsk fəɹ pæsədʒ bæk tə ðə dɔɹweɪ, nɑt noʊɪŋ ɪt hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd. . . .

If Moiraine had not known this, and had not asked for passage out as he had done ... or if she had asked for passage back to the doorway, not knowing it had been destroyed. . . .

mæt hæɾ æsk fəɹ ə weɪ aʊt. ðeɪ hæd ɡɪvən ɪt tə hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz.

Mat had asked for a way out. They had given it to him, but he could not remember what it was.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd ɡɔn blæk, ən i hæɾ əweɪkən hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ.

Everything had gone black, and he had awakened hanging from the ashandarei.

mæt pʊl sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, hoʊldɪŋ ɪt taɪtli ɪn ɪz fɪst. "ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪn hɪɹ sʌmhaʊ," hɪz wɪspɝd. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə kɝɛk pæθweɪ."

Mat pulled something from his pocket, holding it tightly in his fist. "The Aelfinn and the Eelfinn get around in here somehow," his whispered. "There has to be a correct pathway."

"wʌn weɪ," noʊl sɛd. "fɔɹ tʃɔɪsəz, fɑloʊd baɪ fɔɹ tʃɔɪsəz, fɑloʊd baɪ fɔɹ tʃɔɪsəz . . .

"One way," Noal said. "Four choices, followed by four choices, followed by four choices . . .

ði ɑdz əɡɛnst əs ɑɹ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl!"

The odds against us are incredible!"

"ɑdz," mæt sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz hænd. hi oʊpən ɪt, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə daɪs. "wʌt də / kɛɹ fəɹ ɑdz?"

"Odds," Mat said, holding out his hand. He opened it, revealing a pair of dice. "What do / care for odds?"

ðə tu lʊkt əɾ ɪz aɪvɝi daɪs, ðən lʊk bæk ʌp əɾ ɪz feɪs. mæt kəd fil ɪz lʌk sɝdʒ.

The two looked at his ivory dice, then looked back up at his face. Mat could feel his luck surge.

"twɛlv pɪps. θɹi fəɹ itʃ dɔɹweɪ. ɪf aɪ ɹoʊl ə wʌn, ə tu, əɹ ə θɹi, wi ɡoʊ stʃɹeɪt. fɔɹ, faɪv, əɹ sɪks, wi teɪk ðə ɹaɪt pæθ, ən soʊ ɑn."

"Twelve pips. Three for each doorway. If I roll a one, a two, or a three, we go straight. Four, five, or six, we take the right path, and so on."

"bʌt mæt," noʊl wɪspɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə slipɪŋ ɛlfɪn. "ðə ɹoʊlz woʊn bi ikwəl. jə kæn ɹoʊl ə wʌn, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ən ə sɛvən ɪz fɑɹ mɔɹ laɪkli tə - "

"But Mat," Noal whispered, glancing at the sleeping Eelfinn. "The rolls won't be equal. You can't roll a one, for example, and a seven is far more likely to - "

"ju doʊn ʌndɝstænd, noʊl," mæt sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ðə daɪs tə ðə flɔɹ. ðeɪ ɹæɾəld əɡɛns ðə skeɪl-laɪk taɪlz, klækɪŋ laɪk tiθ. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪz laɪkli. nɑt wən aɪm ɝaʊnd."

"You don't understand, Noal," Mat said, tossing the dice to the floor. They rattled against the scale-like tiles, clacking like teeth. "It doesn't matter what is likely. Not when I'm around."

ðə daɪs keɪm tə ə ɹɛst. wʌn ə ðɛm kɑɾ ɪn ə ɹʌt bɪtwin tu taɪlz ən fɹoʊz pɹɪkɛɹiəsli, wʌn ə ðə kɔɹnɝz tə ði ɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ keɪm tə ɹɛst wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl pɪp ʃoʊɪŋ.

The dice came to a rest. One of them caught in a rut between two tiles and froze precariously, one of the corners to the air. The other came to rest with a single pip showing.

"haʊ əbaʊt ðæt, noʊl," θɔɹn sɛd. "lʊks laɪk i kən ɹoʊl ə wʌn æftɝ ɔl."

"How about that, Noal," Thorn said. "Looks like he can roll a one after all."

"naʊ ðæts sʌmθɪŋ," noʊl sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn.

"Now that's something," Noal said, rubbing his chin.

mæt fɛtʃt ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, ðən pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs ən wɔk stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊd, livɪŋ ðə slipɪŋ ɛlfɪn bɪhaɪnd.

Mat fetched his ashandarei, then picked up the dice and walked straight ahead. The others followed, leaving the sleeping Eelfinn behind.

ət ðə nɛkst ɪntɝsɛkʃən, mæt ɹoʊld əɡɛn, ən ɡɑɾ ə naɪn. "bæk ðə weɪ wi keɪm?" θɔɹn æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ðæts - "

At the next intersection, Mat rolled again, and got a nine. "Back the way we came?" Thorn asked, frowning. "That's - "

"dʒʌst wʌt wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ən ɡoʊɪŋ bæk. ɪn ði ʌðɝ ɹum, ðə slipɪŋ ɛlfɪn wɑz ɡɔn.

"Just what we're going to do," Mat said, turning and going back. In the other room, the sleeping Eelfinn was gone.

"ðeɪ cʊɾə wækən hɪm," noʊl pɔɪntəɾ aʊt.

"They could have wakened him," Noal pointed out.

"ɔɹ ɪt kəd bi ə dɪfɹən ɹum," mæt sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ðə daɪs əɡɛn. ənʌðɝ naɪn. hi wɑz feɪsɪŋ ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm, soʊ ə naɪn mɛnt ɡoʊɪŋ bæk əɡɛn. "ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn əv ɹulz," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ən ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ði ʌðɝ tu tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ hɪm. "æn ðɪs pleɪs əz ɹulz."

"Or it could be a different room," Mat said, tossing the dice again. Another nine. He was facing the way he had come, so a nine meant going back again. "The Aelfinn and the Eelfinn have rules," Mat said, turning and running down the corridor, the other two chasing after him. "And this place has rules."

"ɹulz əv tə meɪk sɛns, mæt," noʊl sɛd.

"Rules have to make sense, Mat," Noal said.

"ðeɪ hæv tə bi kənsɪstənt," mæt sɛd. "bʌt ðeɪ doʊn əv tə fɑloʊ əɹ lɑdʒɪk. waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ?"

"They have to be consistent," Mat said. "But they don't have to follow our logic. Why should they?"

ɪt meɪd sɛns tə hɪm. ðeɪ ɹæn fəɹ ə taɪm - ðɪs hɔlweɪ simd mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ði ʌðɝz. hi wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə fil wɪndɪd wən i ɹitʃt ðə nɛkst ɹum. hi tɔs ðə daɪs əɡɛn, bʌt səspɛktəd wʌɾ i wəd si naɪn. bæk tə ðə fɝst ɹum əɡɛn.

It made sense to him. They ran for a time - this hallway seemed much longer than the others. He was starting to feel winded when he reached the next room. He tossed the dice again, but suspected what he would see Nine. Back to the first room again.

"lʊk, ðɪs ɪz fulɪʃ!" noʊl sɛɾ əz ðeɪ tɝn ən ɹæn bæk ði ʌðɝ weɪ. "wɝ nɛvɝ gɑnə ɡɛɾ ɛniwɛɹ ðɪs weɪ!"

"Look, this is foolish!" Noal said as they turned and ran back the other way. "We're never going to get anywhere this way!"

mæt ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə ɹʌn. sun ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə fɝst ɹum əɡɛn.

Mat ignored him, continuing to run. Soon they approached the first room again.

"mæt," noʊl sɛd, pliɾɪŋli. "kæn wi ət list. . . ."

"Mat," Noal said, pleadingly. "Can we at least. . . ."

noʊl tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ðeɪ bɝst ɪndə ðə fɝs tʃeɪmbɝ. oʊnli ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs tʃeɪmbɝ. ðɪs ɹum hæɾ ə waɪt flɔɹ, ən wɑz ɪnɔɹməs, wɪð θɪk, blæk kɑləmz ɹaɪzɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ən ənsin silɪŋ fɑɹ əbʌv.

Noal trailed off as they burst into the first chamber. Only it was not the first chamber. This room had a white floor, and was enormous, with thick, black columns rising toward an unseen ceiling far above.

ðə ɡloʊɪŋ waɪt stim ðət puld ətɑp ðɛɹ kɔɹəɾɝ pɔɹɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum ən fɛl ʌpwɝɾ ɪndə ðət blæknəs, laɪk ə wɔɾɝfɔl ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ dɝɛkʃən. ðoʊ ðə flɔɹ ən ðə kɑləmz lʊk laɪk ɡlæs, mæt nu ðeɪ wəd fil pɔɹəs, laɪk stoʊn. ðə ɹum wɑz lɪt baɪ ə sɪɹiz ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ jɛloʊ stʃɹaɪps ðət ɹæn ʌp itʃ kɑləm, mɑɹkɪŋ pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðə kɑɹvd ɡlæs-stoʊn wɑz fluɾəd tə ə pɔɪnt.

The glowing white steam that pooled atop their corridor poured into the room and fell upward into that blackness, like a waterfall going in the wrong direction. Though the floor and the columns looked like glass, Mat knew they would feel porous, like stone. The room was lit by a series of glowing yellow stripes that ran up each column, marking places where the carved glass-stone was fluted to a point.

θɔɹn klæpt ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "mæt, læd, ðət wɑz ɪnseɪn. ən ɪfɛktɪv. sʌmhaʊ."

Thorn clapped him on the shoulder. "Mat, lad, that was insane. And effective. Somehow."

"əbaʊt wʌt jə ʃəɾ ɪkspɛk fɹəm mi," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ daʊn ðə bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt. "aɪv bɪn ɪn ðɪs ɹum bɪfɔɹ. wɝ ɑn tʃɹæk. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn stɪl laɪvz, ðən ʃɪl bi sʌmwɛɹ pæs hɪɹ."

"About what you should expect from me," Mat said, pulling down the brim of his hat. "I've been in this room before. We're on track. If Moiraine still lives, then she'll be somewhere past here."


tʃæptɝ fɪftifɔɹ


CHAPTER 54

ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝld


The Light of the World

tɑm hɛld ʌp ɪz tɔɹtʃ, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ði ɪnɔɹməs stɑɹ-ʃeɪp blæk kɑləmz ən ðɛɹ ɡloʊɪŋ jɛloʊ laɪnz. ðoʊz laɪnz ɡeɪv ði ɪntaɪɝ ɹum ə sɪkli laɪt, meɪkɪŋ θɔɹn lʊk wɑn ən dʒɔndɪst.

Thom held up his torch, inspecting the enormous star-shaped black columns and their glowing yellow lines. Those lines gave the entire room a sickly light, making Thorn look wan and jaundiced.

mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə stɪŋk ə ðɪs pleɪs, ðət mʌsti steɪlnəs. naʊ ðəɾ i nu wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ, hi kəd smɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, tu. ðə mʌski stɪŋk ʌv ən ænəməlz dɛn. ə pɹɛɾətɝz lɛɹ.

Mat remembered the stink of this place, that musty staleness. Now that he knew what to look for, he could smell something else, too. The musky stink of an animal's den. A predator's lair.

ðəɹ wɝ faɪv kɔɹɪɾɝz liɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, wʌn əɾ itʃ ɪnɝ pɔɪn ə ðə stɑɹ ʃeɪp. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd pæsɪŋ θɹu wʌn ə ðoʊz pɑsɑdʒweɪz, bʌt hæd ðəɹ nɑt bɪn oʊnli wʌn weɪ aʊt bɪfɔɹ?

There were five corridors leading out of the room, one at each inner point of the star shape. He remembered passing through one of those passageways, but had there not been only one way out before?

"wʌndɝ haʊ haɪ ʌp ðə pɪlɝz ɡoʊ," θɔɹn sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz tɔɹtʃ haɪɝ ən skwɪntɪŋ.

"Wonder how high up the pillars go," Thorn said, raising his torch higher and squinting.

mæt hɛld ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn ə fɝmɝ ɡɹɪp, pɑmz swɛɾi. ðeɪ hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə fɑksəz' dɛn. hi fɛlt əɾ ɪz mədæljən. ði ɛln hæd nɑt juz ðə paʊɝ ɑn ɪm bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðeɪ hæd tə hæv səm ʌndɝstændɪŋ ʌv ɪt, dɪd ðeɪ nɑt? ʌv kɔɹs, oʊɡiɝ kəd nɑt tʃænəl. pɝhæps ðət mɛn ɛlfɪn kəd nɑɾ iðɝ.

Mat held his ashandarei in a firmer grip, palms sweaty. They had entered the foxes' den. He felt at his medallion. The Eelnnn had not used the Power on him before, but they had to have some understanding of it, did they not? Of course, Ogier could not channel. Perhaps that meant Eelfinn could not either.

ɹʌslɪŋ saʊnz keɪm fɹəm ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə ɹum. ʃædoʊz ʃɪftəɾ ən muvd. ði ɛln wɝ ɪn ðɛɹ, ɪn ðət dɑɹknəs. "θɔɹn," mæt sɛd. "wi ʃəd pleɪ səm mɔɹ mjuzɪk."

Rustling sounds came from the edges of the room. Shadows shifted and moved. The Eelnnn were in there, in that darkness. "Thorn," Mat said. "We should play some more music."

θɔɹn wɑtʃt ðət dɑɹknəs. hi dɪd nɑɾ əbdʒɛkt; hi ɹeɪzd ɪz fluɾ ən bɪɡæn pleɪɪŋ. ðə saʊn sim loʊnli ɪn ðə væst ɹum.

Thorn watched that darkness. He did not object; he raised his flute and began playing. The sound seemed lonely in the vast room.

"mæt," noʊl sɛd, nilɪŋ nɪɹ ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum. "lʊk ət ðɪs."

"Mat," Noal said, kneeling near the center of the room. "Look at this."

"aɪ noʊ," mæt sɛd. "ɪt lʊks laɪk ɡlæs bʌt filz laɪk stoʊn."

"I know," Mat said. "It looks like glass but feels like stone."

"noʊ, nɑt ðæt," noʊl sɛd. "ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ hɪɹ."

"No, not that," Noal said. "There's something here."

mæt ɛdʒd oʊvɝ tə noʊl. θɔɹn dʒɔɪn ðɛm, wɑtʃɪŋ ən pleɪɪŋ əz noʊl juzd ɪz læntɝn tə ɪlumɪnɪɾ ə mɛltəd lʌmp ə slæɡ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, pɝhæps ðə saɪz ʌv ə smɔl tʃɛst. ɪt wɑz blæk, bʌɾ ə dipɝ, lɛs ɹɪflɛktɪv blæk ðən ðə flɔɹ ən ðə kɑləmz.

Mat edged over to Noal. Thorn joined them, watching and playing as Noal used his lantern to illuminate a melted lump of slag on the floor, perhaps the size of a small chest. It was black, but a deeper, less reflective black than the floor and the columns.

"wʌt dʒju meɪk ʌv ɪt?" noʊl æskt. "meɪbi wʌn ə ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹz?"

"What do you make of it?" Noal asked. "Maybe one of the trapdoors?"

"noʊ," mæt sɛd. "ɪts nɑt ðæt."

"No," Mat said. "It's not that."

ði ʌðɝ tu lʊkt ət hɪm.

The other two looked at him.

"ɪts ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm," mæt sɛd, filɪŋ sɪk. "ðə ɹɛd stoʊn dɔɹfɹeɪm. wən aɪ keɪm θɹu ɪt bɪfɔɹ, ɪt wɑz ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ə ɹum laɪk ðɪs. wən ɪt mɛltəɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd . . ."

"It's the doorframe," Mat said, feeling sick. "The red stone doorframe. When I came through it before, it was in the center of a room like this. When it melted on the other side . . ."

"ɪt mɛltəd hɪɹ tu," noʊl sɛd.

"It melted here too," Noal said.

ðə θɹi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt. θɔɹnz mjuzɪk saʊndəd hɔntɪŋ.

The three stared at it. Thorn's music sounded haunting.

"wɛl," mæt sɛd. "wi nu ɪt wɑzn ə weɪ aʊɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. wɪl əv tə bɑɹɡən əɹ weɪ fɹi." ən əl meɪk blʌɾi ʃʊɹ nɑt tə ɡɛt hæŋ ðɪs taɪm.

"Well," Mat said. "We knew it wasn't a way out in the first place. We'll have to bargain our way free." And I'll make bloody sure not to get hanged this time.

"wɪl ðə daɪs lɛɾ ʌs?" noʊl æskt, ɹaɪzɪŋ.

"Will the dice lead us?" Noal asked, rising.

mæt fɛlt əm ɪn ɪz koʊt pɑkət. "aɪ doʊn si waɪ nɑt." bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt teɪk əm aʊt. hi tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd ðə dɛpθs ə ðə ɹum. θɔɹnz mjuzɪk sim tə hæv stɪl səm ə ðə ʃædoʊz. bʌɾ ʌðɝz stɪl muvd. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɛsləs ɛnɝdʒi tə ði ɛɹ.

Mat felt them in his coat pocket. "I don't see why not." But he did not take them out. He turned to regard the depths of the room. Thorn's music seemed to have stilled some of the shadows. But others still moved. There was a restless energy to the air.

"mæt?" θɔɹn æskt.

"Mat?" Thorn asked.

"ju nu aɪd kʌm bæk," mæt sɛd laʊdli. hɪz vɔɪs dɪd nɑɾ ɛkoʊ. laɪt! haʊ lɑɹdʒ wɑz ðə θɪŋ? "ju nu aɪd kʌm mɑɹtʃɪŋ bæk tə jəɹ blʌɾi ɹɛlm, dɪdn ju? jə nu juɾ əv mi ɪvɛntʃəwəli."

"You knew I'd come back," Mat said loudly. His voice did not echo. Light! How large was the thing? "You knew I'd come marching back to your bloody realm, didn't you? You knew you'd have me eventually."

hɛzɪɾənt, θɔɹn loʊɝɾ ɪz flut.

Hesitant, Thorn lowered his flute.

"ʃoʊ jʊɹsɛlvz!" mæt sɛd. "aɪ kən hɪɹ jə skɹæmbəlɪŋ, hɪɹ jə bɹiðɪŋ."

"Show yourselves!" Mat said. "I can hear you scrambling, hear you breathing."

"mæt," tɑm sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðeɪ kʊdn əv noʊn ðət jud kʌm bæk. mɔɪɹeɪn dɪdnt noʊ ðət jud kʌm fəɹ sɝɾən."

"Mat," Thom said, laying a hand on his shoulder. "They couldn't have known that you'd come back. Moiraine didn't know that you'd come for certain."

mæt wɑtʃt ðə dɑɹknəs. "ju ɛvɝ si mɛn lɛd kæɾəl tə slɔɾɝ, tɑm?"

Mat watched the darkness. "You ever see men lead cattle to slaughter, Thom?"

ðə ɡlimən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

The gleeman hesitated, then shook his head.

"wɛl, ɛvɹi mæn əz ɪz oʊn weɪz," mæt sɛd. "bʌt kæɾəl, si, ðəl noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ.

"Well, every man has his own ways," Mat said. "But cattle, see, they'll know something is wrong.

ðəl smɛl ðə blʌd. ðəl ɡɛt fɹɛnzid, ɹəfjuz tə ɛntɝ ðə slɔɾɝhaʊs. ən jə noʊ haʊ jə fɪks ðæt?"

They'll smell the blood. They'll get frenzied, refuse to enter the slaughterhouse. And you know how you fix that?"

"du wɪv tə tɔk əbaʊt ðɪs naʊ, mæt?"

"Do we have to talk about this now, Mat?"

"ju fɪks ɪt," mæt sɛd, "baɪ teɪkɪŋ əm θɹu ðə slɔɾɝhaʊs ə fju taɪmz wən ɪts klin, wən ðə sɛns ɑɹən soʊ stʃɹɔŋ. jə lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ θɹu ən ɪskeɪp, si, ən ðəl θɪŋk ðə pleɪs ɪz seɪf." hi lʊkt ət tɑm. "ðeɪ nu aɪd bi bæk. ðeɪ nu aɪd sɝvaɪv ðət hæŋɪŋ. ðeɪ noʊ θɪŋz, tɑm. bɝn mi, bʌt ðeɪ du."

"You fix it," Mat said, "by taking them through the slaughterhouse a few times when it is clean, when the scents aren't so strong. You let them go through and escape, see, and they'll think the place is safe." He looked at Thom. "They knew I'd be back. They knew I'd survive that hanging. They know things, Thom. Burn me, but they do."

"wil ɡɛɾ aʊt, mæt," tɑm pɹɑməst. "wi kæn. mɔɪɹeɪn sɔ ɪt."

"We'll get out, Mat," Thom promised. "We can. Moiraine saw it."

mæt nɑɾəd fɝmli. "blʌɾi ɹaɪt wi wɪl. ðəɹ pleɪɪŋ ə ɡeɪm, tɑm. aɪ wɪn ɡeɪmz." hi pʊld ə hændfʊl ə daɪs fɹəm ɪz pɑkət. wʌn wɪn əm moʊst ə ðə taɪm, ɛniweɪ.

Mat nodded firmly. "Bloody right we will. They're playing a game, Thom. I win games." He pulled a handful of dice from his pocket. 1 win them most of the time, anyway.

ə vɔɪs wɪspɝd sʌɾənli fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðɛm. "wɛlkəm, sʌn ə bæɾəlz."

A voice whispered suddenly from behind them. "Welcome, son of battles."

mæt spʌn, kɝsɪŋ, ɡlænsɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tʃeɪmbɝ.

Mat spun, cursing, glancing about the chamber.

"ðɛɹ," noʊl sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ wɪð ɪz stæf. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɪɡjɝ bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə pɪlɝz, hæf lɪt baɪ ðə jɛloʊ laɪt. ənʌðɝ ɛlfɪn. tɔlɝ, hɪz feɪs mɔɹ æŋɡjəlɝ. hɪz aɪz ɹəflɛktəd tɔɹtʃlaɪt. ɔɹənʒ.

"There," Noal said, pointing with his staff. There was a figure beside one of the pillars, half lit by the yellow light. Another Eelfinn. Taller, his face more angular. His eyes reflected torchlight. Orange.

"aɪ kən teɪk jə wɛɹ jə wɪʃ tə ɡoʊ," ði ɛlfɪn sɛd, vɔɪs ɹʌf ən ɡɹævəli. hi ɹeɪzd ən ɑɹm əɡɛns ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə tɔɹtʃɪz. "fɔɹ ə pɹaɪs."

"I can take you where you wish to go," the Eelfinn said, voice rough and gravelly. He raised an arm against the glow of the torches. "For a price."

"tɑm, mjuzɪk."

"Thom, music."

tɑm bɪɡæn pleɪɪŋ əɡɛn.

Thom began playing again.

"wʌn ə jə ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ əs tə liv əɹ tulz bɪhaɪnd," mæt sɛd. hi pʊld ə tɔɹtʃ fɹəm ðə pæk oʊvɝ ɪz ɑɹm, ðən θɹʌst ɪt tə ðə saɪd, laɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn noʊlz læntɝn. "ɪt woʊnt wɝk."

"One of you already tried to get us to leave our tools behind," Mat said. He pulled a torch from the pack over his arm, then thrust it to the side, lighting it on Noal's lantern. "It won't work."

ði ɛlfɪn ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə nu laɪt, snɑɹlɪŋ sɔfli. "ju kʌm lʊkɪŋ tə bɑɹɡən, jɛt jə pɝpəsli æntæɡənaɪz? wɪv dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə ɝn ðɪs."

The Eelfinn shied away from the new light, snarling softly. "You come looking to bargain, yet you purposely antagonize? We have done nothing to earn this."

mæt pʊl ðə skɑɹf fɹi fɹəm ɪz nɛk. "nʌθɪŋ?"

Mat pulled the scarf free from his neck. "Nothing?"

ðə kɹitʃɝ meɪd noʊ ɹɪspɑns, ðoʊ ɪt dɪd bæk əweɪ, stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹkɝ ɛɹiə bɪtwin pɪlɝz. ɪts tu-æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs wɑz naʊ oʊnli bɛɹli lɪt baɪ ðə jɛloʊ laɪts.

The creature made no response, though it did back away, stepping into the darker area between pillars. Its too-angular face was now only barely lit by the yellow lights.

"waɪ dʒju wɪʃ tə spik wɪð ʌs, sʌn ə bæɾəlz," ðə wɪspɝɝ sɛd fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz, "ɪf jə ɑɹ nɑt wɪlɪŋ tə bɑɹɡən?"

"Why do you wish to speak with us, son of battles," the whisperer said from the shadows, "if you are not willing to bargain?"

"noʊ," mæt sɛd. "noʊ bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ əntɪl wi ɹitʃ ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl, ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ə bɑnz." ðət wɑz ði oʊnli pleɪs wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd bi baʊn tə ði əɡɹimənt. ɪz ðət nɑt wʌt bɝdʒɪt hæd sɛd? ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd sim tə bi ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn stɔɹiz ən hɪɹseɪ hɝsɛlf.

"No," Mat said. "No bargaining until we reach the great hall, the Chamber of Bonds." That was the only place where they would be bound to the agreement. Is that not what Birgitte had said? Of course, she had seemed to be relying on stories and hearsay herself.

tɑm kəntɪnjud pleɪɪŋ, aɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ðə ʃædoʊz. noʊl bɪɡæn tə pleɪ ðə lɪɾəl sɪmbəlz i hæd taɪd tə ðə lɛɡz ə hɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz, tæpɪŋ əm ɪn taɪm wɪð tɑmz mjuzɪk. ðə ʃædoʊz kəntɪnjud tə muv aʊt ðɛɹ, haʊɛvɝ.

Thom continued playing, eyes darting from side to side, trying to watch the shadows. Noal began to play the little cymbals he had tied to the legs of his trousers, tapping them in time with Thom's music. The shadows continued to move out there, however.

"jɔɹ . . . kʌmfɝts wɪl nɑt sloʊ ʌs, sʌn ə bæɾəlz," ə vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. mæt spʌn, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz wɛpən. ənʌðɝ ɛlfɪn stʊd ðɛɹ, dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ʃædoʊz. ə fimeɪl, wɪð ə kɹɛst ə ɹɛd ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk, ðə lɛðɝ stʃɹæps kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ bɹɛsts ɪn ən 'ɛks' pæɾɝn. hɝ ɹɛd lɪps smaɪld. "wi ɑɹ ðə nɪɹ eɪntʃənt, ðə wɔɹiɝz ə faɪnəl ɹəɡɹɛt, ðə noʊɝz ə sikɹəts."

"Your . . . comforts will not slow us, son of battles," a voice said from behind. Mat spun, lowering his weapon. Another Eelfinn stood there, just inside the shadows. A female, with a crest of red running down her back, the leather straps crossing her breasts in an 'X' pattern. Her red lips smiled. "We are the near ancient, the warriors of final regret, the knowers of secrets."

"bi pɹaʊd, sʌn ə bæɾəlz," ənʌðɝ vɔɪs hɪst. mæt spʌn əɡɛn, swɛt dæmpənɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊ. ðə fimeɪl vænɪʃt bæk ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ ɛlfɪn stʃɹoʊl θɹu ðə laɪt. hi kæɹiɾ ə lɔŋ, wɪkəd bɹɑnz naɪf, wɪð ə kɹɔswɝk pæɾɝn ə ɹoʊzɪz əlɔŋ ɪts lɛŋθ ən θɔɹnz stɪkɪŋ aʊt nɪɹ ðə tɑp ə ðə kɹɔsɡɑɹd. "ju dʒɹɔ aʊɾ əɹ moʊst skɪl jə ɑɹ tə bi . . . seɪvɝd."

"Be proud, son of battles," another voice hissed. Mat spun again, sweat dampening his brow. The female vanished back into the shadows, but another Eelfinn strolled through the light. He carried a long, wicked bronze knife, with a crosswork pattern of roses along its length and thorns sticking out near the top of the crossguard. "You draw out our most skilled You are to be . . . savored."

"wʌt - " mæt bɪɡæn, bʌt ðə lin, deɪnʒɝəs-lʊkɪŋ ɛlfɪn stɛp bæk ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz ən vænɪʃt. tu kwɪkli. əz ɪf ðə dɑɹknəs hæɾ əbzɔɹb hɪm.

"What - " Mat began, but the lean, dangerous-looking Eelfinn stepped back into the shadows and vanished. Too quickly. As if the darkness had absorbed him.

ʌðɝ wɪspɝz bɪɡæn ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, spikɪŋ ɪn loʊ vɔɪsəz, oʊvɝlæpɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ. feɪsəz əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs, ɪnhjumən aɪz waɪd, lɪps kɝld ɪn smaɪlz. ðə kɹitʃɝz hæd pɔɪntəd tiθ.

Other whispers began in the shadows, speaking in low voices, overlapping each other. Faces appeared from the darkness, inhuman eyes wide, lips curled in smiles. The creatures had pointed teeth.

laɪt! ðəɹ wɝ dʌzənz ʌv ɛlfɪn ɪn ðə ɹum. ʃɪftɪŋ, muvɪŋ əbaʊt, dænsɪŋ ɪndə ðə laɪt, ðən dʒʌmpɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə dɑɹk. səm wɝ kæʒəwəl, ʌðɝz ɛnɝdʒɛɾɪk. ɔl lʊk deɪnʒɝəs.

Light! There were dozens of Eelfinn in the room. Shifting, moving about, dancing into the light, then jumping back into the dark. Some were casual, others energetic. All looked dangerous.

"wɪl jə bɑɹɡən?" wʌn æskt.

"Will you bargain?" one asked.

"ju kʌm wɪθaʊt tʃɹiɾi. deɪnʒɝəs," sɛɾ ənʌðɝ.

"You come without treaty. Dangerous," said another.

"sʌn ə bæɾəlz."

"Son of battles."

"ðə seɪvɝ!"

"The savor!"

"fil ɪz fɪɹ."

"Feel his fear."

"kʌm wɪð ʌs. liv jəɹ tɛɹəbəl laɪt."

"Come with us. Leave your terrible light."

"ə bɑɹɡən mʌs bi meɪd. wɪl weɪt."

"A bargain must be made. We will wait."

"peɪʃənt wi ɑɹ. ɛvɝ peɪʃənt."

"Patient we are. Ever patient."

"ðə seɪvɝ!"

"The savor!"

"stɑp ɪt!" mæt bɛloʊd. "noʊ bɑɹɡənz! nɑɾ əntɪl wi ɹitʃ ðə sɛntɝ."

"Stop it!" Mat bellowed. "No bargains! Not until we reach the center."

əɾ ɪz saɪd, θɔɹn loʊɝd ðə flut. "mæt. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə mjuzɪk ɪz wɝkɪŋ ɛnimɔɹ."

At his side, Thorn lowered the flute. "Mat. I don't think the music is working anymore."

mæt nɑɾəd kɝtli. hi niɾəd tɑm ɹɛɾi wɪð wɛpənz. ðə ɡli-mæn tʌkt əweɪ hɪz flut, ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt naɪvz. mæt ɪɡnɔɹd ðə wɪspɝɪŋ vɔɪsəz ən tɔs ðə daɪs ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Mat nodded curtly. He needed Thom ready with weapons. The glee-man tucked away his flute, getting out knives. Mat ignored the whispering voices and tossed the dice onto the ground.

əz ðeɪ ɹoʊld, ə fɪɡjɝ skʌɾəld fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs bɪsaɪd ðə nɪɹəs pɪlɝ. mæt kɝst, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ ən stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət ði ɛlfɪn, wɪtʃ muvd əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊn ɑn ɔl fɔɹz. bʌɾ ɪz bleɪd pæst ɹaɪt θɹu ɪt, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ smoʊk.

As they rolled, a figure scuttled from the darkness beside the nearest pillar. Mat cursed, lowering his spear and striking at the Eelfinn, which moved across the ground on all fours. But his blade passed right through it, as if it were smoke.

wɑz ɪɾ ən ɪluʒən? ə tʃɹɪk ə ði aɪz? mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ənʌðɝ kɹitʃɝ tə snætʃ ðə daɪs ən lip bæk təwɔɹd ðə ʃædoʊz.

Was it an illusion? A trick of the eyes? Mat hesitated long enough for another creature to snatch the dice and leap back toward the shadows.

sʌmθɪŋ spɑɹkəld ɪn ði ɛɹ. θɔɹnz dæɡɝ faʊn ɪts mɑɹk, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝ ɪn ðə ʃoʊldɝ.

Something sparkled in the air. Thorn's dagger found its mark, striking the creature in the shoulder.

ðɪs taɪm ðə bleɪd pɪɹst ən steɪd, ɹilisɪŋ ə spɹeɪ ʌv dɑɹk blʌd.

This time the blade pierced and stayed, releasing a spray of dark blood.

aɪɝn, mæt θɔt, kɝsɪŋ ɪz stupɪɾɪti. hi spʌn ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɝaʊnd, juzɪŋ ðə saɪd bændɪd wɪð aɪɝn. hi ʃɪvɝɾ əz i sɔ ði ɛlfɪnz blʌɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪɡɪn tə stim. waɪt stim, əz ɪn ði ʌðɝ tʃeɪmbɝz, bʌt ðɪs hæd ʃeɪps ɪn ɪt. ðeɪ lʊk laɪk twɪstəd feɪsəz, əpɪɹɪŋ bɹifli ən jɛlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ vænɪʃɪŋ.

Iron, Mat thought, cursing his stupidity. He spun the ashandarei around, using the side banded with iron. He shivered as he saw the Eelfinn's blood on the ground begin to steam. White steam, as in the other chambers, but this had shapes in it. They looked like twisted faces, appearing briefly and yelling before vanishing.

bɝn ðɛm! hi kʊdnt ɡɛt dɪstʃɹæktəd. hi hæɾ ʌðɝ daɪs. hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz pɑkət, bʌɾ ən ɛlfɪn dʌk fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz, əz ɪf tə ɡɹæb əɾ ɪz koʊt.

Burn them! He couldn't get distracted. He had other dice. He reached for his pocket, but an Eelfinn ducked from the shadows, as if to grab at his coat.

mæt spʌn ɪz wɛpən, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə fɑks meɪlz feɪs wɪð ðə bændɪɾ aɪɝn. hi kɹʌʃt boʊn, tɔsɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝ tə ðə saɪd laɪk ə bʌndəl ə stɪks.

Mat spun his weapon, striking the side of the fox male's face with the banded iron. He crushed bone, tossing the creature to the side like a bundle of sticks.

hɪsɪz ən ɡɹaʊlz sɝaʊndəd ðɛm. aɪz ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ɹəflɛktɪŋ tɔɹtʃlaɪt. ði ɛlfɪn muvd, kloʊkt ɪn blæknəs, sɝaʊndɪŋ mæt ən ði ʌðɝz. mæt kɝst, teɪkɪŋ ə stɛp ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ði ɛlfɪn i hæd stʃɹʌk.

Hisses and growls surrounded them. Eyes shifted in the darkness, reflecting torchlight. The Eelfinn moved, cloaked in blackness, surrounding Mat and the others. Mat cursed, taking a step in the direction of the Eelfinn he had struck.

"mæt!" θɔɹn sɛd, ɡɹæbɪŋ ðə kʌf ə hɪz koʊt. "wi kænt weɪɾ ɪndə ðæt."

"Mat!" Thorn said, grabbing the cuff of his coat. "We can't wade into that."

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɪt sim ðət ðə stɪŋk fɹəm bɪfɔɹ wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ, ðə sɛn ə bists. ʃædoʊz muvd ɔl əbaʊt, mɔɹ fɹæntɪk naʊ, ðɛɹ wɪspɝz æŋɡɹi ən mɪkst wɪð jɪpɪŋ kɔlz.

Mat hesitated. It seemed that the stink from before was stronger, the scent of beasts. Shadows moved all about, more frantic now, their whispers angry and mixed with yipping calls.

"ðeɪ kəntʃɹoʊl ðə dɑɹknəs," noʊl sɛd. hi stʊd wɪð ɪz bæk tə mæt ən θɔɹn, wɛɹi. "ðoʊz jɛloʊ laɪts ɑɹ tə dɪstʃɹækt ʌs; ðəɹ ɑɹ bɹeɪks ɪn əm ən ʃɛltɝɾ ælkoʊvz. ɪts ɔl ə tʃɹɪk."

"They control the darkness," Noal said. He stood with his back to Mat and Thorn, wary. "Those yellow lights are to distract us; there are breaks in them and sheltered alcoves. It's all a trick."

mæt fɛlt ɪz hɑɹt biɾɪŋ ɹæpədli. ə tʃɹɪk? noʊ, nɑt dʒʌst ə tʃɹɪk. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ənnætʃɹəl əbaʊt ðə weɪ ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz muvd ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ. "bɝn ðɛm," mæt sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ θɔɹnz hæn fɹi bʌt nɑt tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

Mat felt his heart beating rapidly. A trick? No, not just a trick. There was something unnatural about the way those creatures moved in the shadow. "Burn them," Mat said, shaking Thorn's hand free but not chasing into the darkness.

"dʒɛntəlmɪn," noʊl sɛd. "ɡæðɝ ɑɹmz. . . ."

"Gentlemen," Noal said. "Gather arms. . . ."

mæt ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðəɹ wɝ ɛlfɪn stɔkɪŋ fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ə dʌbəl weɪv, wʌn ɡɹup slaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɔl fɔɹz bɪfɔɹ ə sɛkənd ɡɹup. ðə sɛkənd ɡɹup kæɹid ðoʊz wɪkəd-lʊkɪŋ bɹɑnz naɪvz.

Mat glanced over his shoulder. There were Eelfinn stalking from the shadows behind them, a double wave, one group sliding on all fours before a second group. The second group carried those wicked-looking bronze knives.

ðə ʃædoʊz fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə ðə ɹum sim tə bi ɪkstɛndɪŋ wɪð ði ɛlfɪn, kloʊzɪŋ ɑn mæt ən ɪz ɡɹup. hɪz hɑɹt biɾ ivən fæstɝ.

The shadows from the depths of the room seemed to be extending with the Eelfinn, closing on Mat and his group. His heart beat even faster.

ði ɛlfɪn aɪz ʃoʊn, ən ðoʊz ɑn ɔl fɔɹz bɪɡæn tə loʊp fɔɹwɝd. mæt swʌŋ əz ði ɛlfɪn ɹitʃt ɪz ɡɹup, bʌt ðeɪ splɪt, dʌkɪŋ tə ðə saɪdz. dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ hɪm.

The Eelfinn eyes shone, and those on all fours began to lope forward. Mat swung as the Eelfinn reached his group, but they split, ducking to the sides. Distracting him.

bɪhaɪnd! mæt θɔt wɪð əlɑɹm. ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ʌv ɛlfɪn dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs ðɛɹ.

Behind! Mat thought with alarm. Another group of Eelfinn jumped out of the darkness there.

mæt tɝn ɑn ðɛm, swɪŋɪŋ. ðeɪ dʌk bæk bɪfɔɹ i hɪt. laɪt' ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɝaʊnd, siθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs, kʌmɪŋ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə bi deɪnʒɝəs, ðən bækɪŋ əweɪ.

Mat turned on them, swinging. They ducked back before he hit. Light' They were all around, seething out of the darkness, coming close enough to be dangerous, then backing away.

θɔɹn wɪpt aʊɾ ə pɛɹ ə dæɡɝz, θɹoʊɪŋ, ən noʊl kɛpt ɪz ʃɔɹtsɔɝɾ ət ðə ɹɛɾi, weɪvɪŋ ɪz tɔɹtʃ wɪð ɪz ʌðɝ hænd, hɪz bændɪd stæf ɑn ðə flɔɹ əɾ ɪz fit. wʌn ə θɔɹnz naɪvz flæʃt, sikɪŋ flɛʃ bʌt mɪst ən pæst ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

Thorn whipped out a pair of daggers, throwing, and Noal kept his shortsword at the ready, waving his torch with his other hand, his banded staff on the floor at his feet. One of Thorn's knives flashed, seeking flesh but missed and passed into the darkness.

"doʊnt weɪs naɪvz!" mæt sɛd. "blʌɾi sʌnz ʌv ɡoʊts, ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk jə weɪs ðɛm, θɔɹn!"

"Don't waste knives!" Mat said. "Bloody sons of goats, they're trying to make you waste them, Thorn!"

"ðeɪɹ hæɹiɪŋ ʌs," noʊl ɡɹaʊld. "ðeɪl oʊvɝwɛlm əs ɪvɛntʃəwəli. wɪv tə muv!"

"They're harrying us," Noal growled. "They'll overwhelm us eventually. We have to move!"

"wɪtʃ weɪ?" θɔɹn æskt, ɝdʒənt. hi kɝst əz ə pɛɹ ʌv ɛlfɪn əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz kæɹiɪŋ bɹɑnz-ɛndəd lænsɪz. ðeɪ θɹʌs fɔɹwɝd, fɔɹsɪŋ mæt, θɔɹn, ən noʊl tə bæk əweɪ.

"Which way?" Thorn asked, urgent. He cursed as a pair of Eelfinn appeared from the shadows carrying bronze-ended lances. They thrust forward, forcing Mat, Thorn, and Noal to back away.

noʊ taɪm fəɹ daɪs. ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst snætʃ ðoʊz ɛniweɪ. mæt jæŋkt oʊpən ɪz pæk ən pʊld aʊɾ ə naɪtfloʊɝ. "wʌns ðɪs ɡoʊz ɔf, aɪm gɑnə kloʊz maɪ aɪz ən spɪn əbaʊt."

No time for dice. They would just snatch those anyway. Mat yanked open his pack and pulled out a nightflower. "Once this goes off, I'm going to close my eyes and spin about."

"wʌt?" θɔɹn sɛd.

"What?" Thorn said.

"ɪts wɝk bɪfɔɹ!" mæt sɛd, laɪɾɪŋ ðə naɪtfloʊɝ ən θɹoʊɪŋ ɪɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz i kəɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ðəɹ wɑz ə kaʊn ə faɪv, ən ðə bum ðət fɑloʊd ɹæɾəld ðə ɹum. ɔl θɹi ʌv əm əvɝɾəd ðɛɹ aɪz, bʌt ðə kʌlɝfəl flæʃ wɑz bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə si θɹu aɪlɪdz.

"It's worked before!" Mat said, lighting the nightflower and throwing it as hard as he could into the darkness. There was a count of five, and the boom that followed rattled the room. All three of them averted their eyes, but the colorful flash was bright enough to see through eyelids.

ɛlfɪn skɹimd ɪn peɪn, ən mæt dɪstɪŋkli hɝd pɪŋz əz wɛpənz wɝ dʒɹɑpt. noʊ daʊt hænz wɝ ɹeɪz tə aɪz.

Eelfinn screamed in pain, and Mat distinctly heard pings as weapons were dropped. No doubt hands were raised to eyes.

"hɪɹ wi ɡoʊ!" mæt sɛd, spɪnɪŋ.

"Here we go!" Mat said, spinning.

"ðɪs ɪz fleɪmɪŋ ɪnseɪn," θɔɹn sɛd.

"This is flaming insane," Thorn said.

mæt kɛpt ɡoʊɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fil fəɹ ɪt. wɛɹ wɑz ðət lʌk? "ðæt weɪ!" hi sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ɪn ə ɹændəm dɝɛkʃən.

Mat kept going, trying to feel for it. Where was that luck? "That way!" he said, pointing in a random direction.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz ɪn taɪm tə lip oʊvɝ ðə dɑɹk fɔɹm ʌv ən ɛlfɪn hʌɾəlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. mæt ən θɔɹn fɑloʊd, ən mæt lɛɾ əm stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. hi tʃɑɹdʒd əhɛɾ əntɪl ɪz fɹɛnz wɝ bɛɹli vɪzəbəl. ɔl i kəd si wɝ ðoʊz laɪnz ə jɛloʊ.

He opened his eyes in time to leap over the dark form of an Eelfinn huddling on the ground. Mat and Thorn followed, and Mat led them straight into the darkness. He charged ahead until his friends were barely visible. All he could see were those lines of yellow.

oʊ, blʌɾi æʃəz, hi θɔt. ɪf maɪ lʌk feɪlz mi naʊ. . . .

Oh, bloody ashes, he thought. If my luck fails me now. . . .

ðeɪ bɝst ɪndə ə faɪv-saɪɾəd kɔɹəɾɝ, ðə dɑɹknəs vænɪʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə si ðɪs kɔɹəɾɝ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɹum, bʌt hɪɹ ɪt wɑz.

They burst into a five-sided corridor, the darkness vanishing around them. They had not been able to see this corridor from the other room, but here it was.

θɔɹn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə wup. "mæt, jə wʊd-hɛɾəd ʃɛpɝd! fəɹ ðɪs, əl lɛt jə pleɪ maɪ hɑɹp!"

Thorn let out a whoop. "Mat, you wood-headed shepherd! For this, I'll let you play my harp!"

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə pleɪ jəɹ blʌɾi hɑɹp," mæt sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "bʌt jə kən baɪ mi ə mʌɡ əɹ tu wən wɝ aʊt."

"I don't want to play your bloody harp," Mat said, glancing over his shoulder. "But you can buy me a mug or two when we're out."

hi hɝd skɹimz ən skɹitʃɪz fɹəm ðə dɑɹk ɹum. ðət wɑz wʌn tʃɹɪk juzd ʌp; ðeɪ wəd bi ɪkspɛktɪŋ naɪtfloʊɝz naʊ. bɝdʒɪt, jə wɝ ɹaɪt, hi θɔt. jə pɹɑbli wɔk pæs ðə kɔɹəɾɝ jə niɾəd sɛvɹəl taɪmz, nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə fju fiɾ əweɪ.

He heard screams and screeches from the dark room. That was one trick used up; they would be expecting nightflowers now. Birgitte, you were right, he thought. You probably walked past the corridor you needed several times, never knowing it was only a few feet away.

nɛvɝ tʃuz ðə kɑɹɾ ə mæn wɑns jə tə. mæt ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪz ðæt. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ði oʊldəs kɑnz ɪn kɹieɪʃən. ðeɪ heɪsən fɔɹwɝd, pæsɪŋ faɪv-saɪɾəd dɔɹweɪz liɾɪŋ ɪndə lɑɹdʒ stɑɹ-ʃeɪp kævɝnz. θɔɹn ən noʊl ɡlænst ɪndə ðɛm, bʌt mæt kɛpt ɑn. stʃɹeɪt fɔɹwɝd. ðɪs wɑz ðə weɪ hɪz lʌk hæd sɛn ðɛm.

Never choose the card a man wants you to. Mat should have realized that. It was one of the oldest cons in creation. They hastened forward, passing five-sided doorways leading into large star-shaped caverns. Thorn and Noal glanced into them, but Mat kept on. Straight forward. This was the way his luck had sent them.

sʌmθɪŋ wɑz dɪfɹən fɹəm wən i hæd vɪzəɾəd bɪfɔɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dʌst ɑn ðə flɔɹ tə meɪk fʊtpɹɪns. hæd ðeɪ noʊn i wɑz kʌmɪŋ, ən juz ðə dʌs tə kənfjuz hɪm? əɹ hæd ðeɪ klin ðə pleɪs ðɪs taɪm, noʊɪŋ ðət vɪzəɾɝz maɪɾ ɝaɪv? hu nu ɪn ə ɹɛlm sətʃ əz ðɪs?

Something was different from when he had visited before. There was no dust on the floor to make footprints. Had they known he was coming, and used the dust to confuse him? Or had they cleaned the place this time, knowing that visitors might arrive? Who knew in a realm such as this?

ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ wɔk bɪfɔɹ. əɹ hæɾ ɪt bɪn ə ʃɔɹt wʌn? taɪm blɛndəd hɪɹ. ɪt sim ðət ðeɪ ɹæn fəɹ mɛni aʊɝz, jɛɾ ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ fɛlt laɪk moʊməns.

It had been a long walk before. Or had it been a short one? Time blended here. It seemed that they ran for many hours, yet it also felt like moments.

ən ðən ðə dɔɹweɪ wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, əpɪɹɪŋ laɪk ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ æɾɝ. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ðəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ. ðə ɹɪm ə ði oʊpənɪŋ wɑz ɪntʃɹəkətli kɑɹvd wʊd, wɪð ən ɪmpɑsəbəl pæɾɝn ʌv wivɪŋ vaɪnz ðət sim tə dʌbəl bæk ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ ən meɪk noʊ sɛns.

And then the doorway was in front of them, appearing like a striking adder. It had not been there a moment before. The rim of the opening was intricately carved wood, with an impossible pattern of weaving vines that seemed to double back on one another and make no sense.

ɔl θɹi pʊl tə ə hɔlt. "mɪɹɝz," noʊl sɛd. "aɪv sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ. ðæts haʊ ðeɪ də ɪt, əbskjʊɹɪŋ θɪŋz wɪð mɪɹɝz." hi saʊndəɾ ənnɝvd. wɛɹ dɪd wʌn haɪd mɪɹɝz ɪn ə blʌɾi stʃɹeɪt tʌnəl?

All three pulled to a halt. "Mirrors," Noal said. "I've seen it before. That's how they do it, obscuring things with mirrors." He sounded unnerved. Where did one hide mirrors in a bloody straight tunnel?

ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs; mæt kəd smɛl ɪt. ðə stɪŋk ə ði ɛlfɪn wɑz stʃɹɔŋɡəs hɪɹ. hi sɛɾ ɪz dʒɔ ən stɛp θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ.

They were in the right place; Mat could smell it. The stink of the Eelfinn was strongest here. He set his jaw and stepped through the doorway.

ðə ɹum bɪɑnd wɑz əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt. noʊ kɑləmz hɪɹ, ðoʊ ðə ɹum wɑz dɪstɪŋkli stɑɹ- ʃeɪpt. eɪt tɪps ən oʊnli ðə wʌn dɔɹweɪ. ðoʊz ɡloʊɪŋ jɛloʊ stʃɹɪps ɹæn ʌp ðə ʃɑɹp ɛnz ə ðə ɹum, ən eɪɾ ɛmpti pɛɾəstəlz stʊd, blæk ən ɑmənəs, wʌn əɾ itʃ pɔɪnt.

The room beyond was as he remembered it. No columns here, though the room was distinctly star- shaped. Eight tips and only the one doorway. Those glowing yellow strips ran up the sharp ends of the room, and eight empty pedestals stood, black and ominous, one at each point.

ɪt wɑz ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wʊmən floʊɾɪŋ əɾ ɪts sɛntɝ.

It was exactly the same. Except for the woman floating at its center.

ʃi wɑz kloʊðd oʊnli ɪn ə faɪn waɪt mɪs ðət ʃɪftəɾ ən ʃoʊn ɝaʊn hɝ, ðə dɪteɪlz ə hɝ fɪɡjɝ ɑbfəskeɪɾɪd bʌt nɑt hɪɾən. hɝ aɪz wɝ kloʊzd, ən əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ - kɝli bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪn pɝfəkt ɹɪŋləts -  flʌɾɝd əz ɪf ɪn ə wɪn bloʊɪŋ ʌp fɹəm bɪniθ. hɝ hænz ɹɛstəɾ ətɑp əɹ stʌmək, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ bɹeɪsləɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ ðət lʊk laɪk eɪdʒd aɪvɝi ɑn əɹ lɛft ɹɪst.

She was clothed only in a fine white mist that shifted and shone around her, the details of her figure obfuscated but not hidden. Her eyes were closed, and her dark hair - curly but no longer in perfect ringlets -  fluttered as if in a wind blowing up from beneath. Her hands rested atop her stomach, and there was a strange bracelet of something that looked like aged ivory on her left wrist.

mɔɪɹeɪn.

Moiraine.

mæt fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz. wɝi, fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, kənsɝn, ɑ. ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd stɑɹɾəd ðɪs ɔl. hi hæd heɪɾəd əɹ ət taɪmz. hi ɔlsoʊ oʊɾ əɹ ɪz laɪf. ʃi wɑz ðə fɝst wʌn u hæd mɛɾəld, jæŋkɪŋ ɪm ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. jɛt - lʊkɪŋ bæk - hi fɪɡjɝd ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ðə moʊst ɑnəst əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn u hæd juz hɪm. ʌnəpɑlədʒɛɾɪk, ənjildɪŋ. ən sɛlfləs.

Mat felt a surge of emotions. Worry, frustration, concern, awe. She was the one who had started this all. He had hated her at times. He also owed her his life. She was the first one who had meddled, yanking him this way and that. Yet - looking back - he figured that she had been the most honest about it of anyone who had used him. Unapologetic, unyielding. And selfless.

ʃi hæd dɛɾəkeɪtəd ɛvɹiθɪŋ tə pɹətɛktɪŋ θɹi fulɪʃ bɔɪz, ɔl ɪɡnɝən ʌv wʌt ðə wɝld wəd dɪmæn ə ðɛm. ʃi hæd dɪtɝmən tə teɪk əm tə seɪfti. meɪbi tʃɹeɪn əm ə lɪɾəl, wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪɾ əɹ nɑt.

She had dedicated everything to protecting three foolish boys, all ignorant of what the world would demand of them. She had determined to take them to safety. Maybe train them a little, whether they wanted it or not.

kəz ðeɪ niɾəd ɪt.

Because they needed it.

laɪt, hɝ moʊɾɪvz sim klɪɹ tə hɪm naʊ. ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk ɪm ɛni lɛs æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd meɪk ɪm ɡɹeɪtfəl. bɝn hɝ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə kənfjuzɪŋ sɛɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz! ðoʊz blʌɾi fɑksəz - haʊ dɛɹ ðeɪ kip əɹ laɪk ðɪs! wɑz ʃi əlaɪv?

Light, her motives seemed clear to him now. That did not make him any less angry with her, but it did make him grateful. Burn her, but this was a confusing set of emotions! Those bloody foxes - how dare they keep her like this! Was she alive?

θɔɹn ən noʊl wɝ stɛɹɪŋ - noʊl sɑləm, θɔɹn dɪsbɪlivɪŋ. soʊ mæt stɛp fɔɹwɝd tə pʊl mɔɪɹeɪn fɹi. əz sun əz ɪz hænz tʌtʃt ðə mɪst, haʊɛvɝ, hi fɛlt ə bleɪzɪŋ peɪn. hi skɹimd, pʊlɪŋ bæk, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hænd.

Thorn and Noal were staring - Noal solemn, Thorn disbelieving. So Mat stepped forward to pull Moiraine free. As soon as his hands touched the mist, however, he felt a blazing pain. He screamed, pulling back, shaking his hand.

"ɪts blʌɾi hɑt" mæt sɛd. "ɪt - "

"It's bloody hot" Mat said. "It - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz θɔɹn stɛp fɔɹwɝd.

He cut off as Thorn stepped forward.

"tɑm . . ." mæt sɛd wɔɹnɪŋli.

"Thom . . ." Mat said warningly.

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ," ðə ɡlimən sɛd. hi stɛpt ʌp tə ðə mɪst, ɹitʃɪŋ ɪn, hɪz kloʊðɪŋ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə stim, hɪz aɪz wɔɾɝɪŋ fɹəm ðə peɪn. hi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ. hi dʌɡ ɪndə ðət mɪst ən tʊk hoʊld ə hɝ, ðən pʊld əɹ fɹi. hɝ weɪt sæŋk ɪndə hɪz ɑɹmz, bʌɾ ɪz eɪdʒɪŋ lɪmz wɝ stʃɹɔŋ, ən ʃi lʊk fɹeɪl ɪnʌf ðət ʃi mʌs nɑɾ əv weɪd mʌtʃ.

"I don't care," the gleeman said. He stepped up to the mist, reaching in, his clothing beginning to steam, his eyes watering from the pain. He did not flinch. He dug into that mist and took hold of her, then pulled her free. Her weight sank into his arms, but his aging limbs were strong, and she looked frail enough that she must not have weighed much.

laɪt! mæt hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ smɔl ʃi wɑz. ə ɡʊd hɛd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən i wɑz. tɑm nɛlt, pʊlɪŋ ɔf ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊk ən ɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɪn ɪt. hɝ aɪz wɝ stɪl kloʊzd.

Light! Mat had forgotten how small she was. A good head shorter than he was. Thom knelt, pulling off his gleeman's cloak and wrapping her in it. Her eyes were still closed.

"ɪz ʃi . . ." noʊl æskt.

"Is she . . ." Noal asked.

"ʃi lɪvz," tɑm sɛd kwaɪətli. "aɪ fɛlt əɹ hɑɹtbit." hi tʊk ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɔf əɹ ɑɹm. ɪt wɑz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə mæn bɛn bækwɝd wɪð ɪz ɹɪsts baʊn tə hɪz æŋkəlz, kloʊðd ɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ suɾ ə kloʊðɪŋ. "ɪt lʊks laɪk ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ə səm sɔɹt," tɑm sɛd, tʌkɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz kloʊk pɑkət. "aɪ - "

"She lives," Thom said quietly. "I felt her heartbeat." He took the bracelet off her arm. It was in the shape of a man bent backward with his wrists bound to his ankles, clothed in a strange suit of clothing. "It looks like a ter'angreal of some sort," Thom said, tucking it into his cloak pocket. "I - "

"ɪɾ ɪz ən æŋɡɹil" ə vɔɪs pɹoʊkleɪmd. "stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi nɪɹli sɑŋɡɹil. ɪt kən bi pɑɹɾ ə hɝ pɹaɪs, ʃəd jə wɪʃ tə peɪ ɪt."

"It is an angreal" a voice proclaimed. "Strong enough to be nearly sa'angreal. It can be part of her price, should you wish to pay it."

mæt spʌn. ðə pɛɾəstəlz wɝ naʊ ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ɛlfɪn, fɔɹ meɪlz, fɔɹ fimeɪlz. ɔl eɪt wɔɹ waɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə blæk - waɪt skɝts wɪð stʃɹæps əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛsts fəɹ ðə meɪlz ən blaʊsəz fəɹ ðə fimeɪlz, meɪd fɹəm ðət dɪstɝbɪŋ peɪl sʌbstəns ðət lʊk laɪk skɪn.

Mat spun. The pedestals were now occupied by Eelfinn, four males, four females. All eight wore white instead of black - white skirts with straps across the chests for the males and blouses for the females, made from that disturbing pale substance that looked like skin.

"mɑɹk jəɹ tʌŋz," mæt sɛd tə θɔɹn ən noʊl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənteɪn ɪz wɝi. "spik əmɪs, ən ðəl əv jə stʃɹʌŋ ʌp, kleɪmɪŋ ɪt wɑz jəɹ oʊn dɪzaɪɝ. æsk nʌθɪŋ ə ðɛm."

"Mark your tongues," Mat said to Thorn and Noal, trying to contain his worry. "Speak amiss, and they'll have you strung up, claiming it was your own desire. Ask nothing of them."

ði ʌðɝ tu fɛl saɪlənt, θɔɹn hoʊldɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn kloʊs, noʊl kæɹiɪŋ ɪz tɔɹtʃ ən stæf wɛɹəli, pæk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

The other two fell silent, Thorn holding Moiraine close, Noal carrying his torch and staff warily, pack over his shoulder.

"ðɪs ɪz ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl," mæt sɛd tə ði ɛlfɪn. "ðə pleɪs kɔl ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ə bɑnz. jə mʌst əbaɪd baɪ ðə pæks jə meɪk hɪɹ."

"This is the great hall," Mat said to the Eelfinn. "The place called the Chamber of Bonds. You must abide by the pacts you make here."

"ðə bɑɹɡən əz bɪn ɝeɪnʒd," wʌn ə ði ɛlfɪn meɪlz sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ, ʃoʊɪŋ pɔɪntəd tiθ.

"The bargain has been arranged," one of the Eelfinn males said, smiling, showing pointed teeth.

ði ʌðɝ ɛlfɪn lin ɪn, bɹiðɪŋ dipli, əz ɪf smɛlɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. əɹ ... əz ɪf dʒɹɔɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm mæt ən ði ʌðɝz. bɝdʒɪt hæd sɛd ðət ðeɪ fɛɾ ɔf ɪmoʊʃən.

The other Eelfinn leaned in, breathing deeply, as if smelling something. Or ... as if drawing something from Mat and the others. Birgitte had said that they fed off emotion.

"wʌt bɑɹɡən?" mæt snæpt, ɡlænsɪŋ ɝaʊn ət ðə pɛɾəstəlz. "bɝn ju, wʌt bɑɹɡən?"

"What bargain?" Mat snapped, glancing around at the pedestals. "Burn you, what bargain?"

"ə pɹaɪs mʌs bi peɪd," wʌn sɛd.

"A price must be paid," one said.

"ðə dɪmænz mʌs bi mɛt," sɛɾ ənʌðɝ.

"The demands must be met," said another.
