"ə sækɹəfaɪs mʌs bi ɡɪvən." ðɪs fɹəm wʌn ə ðə fimeɪlz. ʃi smaɪl mɔɹ bɹɔdli ðən ði ʌðɝz. hɝ tiθ wɝ pɔɪntəd, tu.

"A sacrifice must be given." This from one of the females. She smiled more broadly than the others. Her teeth were pointed, too.

"aɪ wɑn ðə weɪ aʊt ɹɪstɔɹɾ əz pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən," mæt sɛd. "aɪ wɑn ɪt bæk wɛɹ ɪt wɑz ən oʊpən əɡɛn. ən aɪm nɑt blʌɾi dʌn nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ, soʊ doʊn əsum ðət ðɪs ɪz maɪ oʊnli ɹɪkwɛst, bɝn ju."

"I want the way out restored as part of the bargain," Mat said. "I want it back where it was and open again. And I'm not bloody done negotiating, so don't assume that this is my only request, burn you."

"ɪt wɪl bi ɹɪstɔɹd," ən ɛlfɪn sɛd. ði ʌðɝz lin fɔɹwɝd. ðeɪ kəd sɛns ɪz dɛspɝeɪʃən. sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm sim dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. ðeɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛkt əs tə meɪk ɪt hɪɹ, mæt θɔt.

"It will be restored," an Eelfinn said. The others leaned forward. They could sense his desperation. Several of them seemed dissatisfied. They didn't expect us to make it here, Mat thought.

ðeɪ doʊn laɪk tə ɹɪsk luzɪŋ ʌs.

They don't like to risk losing us.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə liv ðət weɪ aʊɾ oʊpən əntɪl wi ɡɛt θɹu," mæt kəntɪnjud. "noʊ blɑkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp əɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪt blʌɾi vænɪʃ wən wi ɝaɪv. ən aɪ wɑn ðə weɪ tə bi dɝɛkt, noʊ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɹumz əbaʊt.

"I want you to leave that way out open until we get through," Mat continued. "No blocking it up or making it bloody vanish when we arrive. And I want the way to be direct, no changing rooms about.

ə stʃɹeɪt pæθweɪ. ən jə blʌɾi fɑksəz kænt nɑk əs ʌnkɑnʃəs əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl əs əɹ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðæt."

A straight pathway. And you bloody foxes can't knock us unconscious or try to kill us or anything like that."

ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk ðæt. mæt kɑt sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm fɹaʊnɪŋ. ɡʊd. ðeɪ wəd si ðeɪ wɝ nɑt nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ wɪð ə tʃaɪld.

They did not like that. Mat caught several of them frowning. Good. They would see they were not negotiating with a child.

"wi teɪk hɝ," mæt sɛd. "wi ɡɛɾ aʊt."

"We take her," Mat said. "We get out."

"ðiz dɪmænz ɑɹ ɪkspɛnsɪv," wʌn ə ði ɛlfɪn sɛd. "wʌt wɪl jə peɪ fəɹ ðiz bunz?"

"These demands are expensive," one of the Eelfinn said. "What will you pay for these boons?"

"ðə pɹaɪs əz bɪn sɛt," ənʌðɝ wɪspɝd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

"The price has been set," another whispered from behind.

ən ɪt hæd bɪn. sʌmhaʊ, mæt nu. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm hæd noʊn fɹəm ðə fɝs taɪm i hæd ɹɛd ðət noʊt. ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ spoʊkən tə ði æɛlfɪn ðət fɝs taɪm, wəɾ ɛni ʌv ðɪs əv hæpənd?

And it had been. Somehow, Mat knew. A part of him had known from the first time he had read that note. If he had never spoken to the Aelfinn that first time, would any of this have happened?

laɪkli, hi wəɾ əv daɪd. ðeɪ hæd tə tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ.

Likely, he would have died. They had to tell the truth.

ðeɪ hæd wɔɹn ɪm ʌv ə peɪmən tə kʌm. fəɹ laɪf. fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn.

They had warned him of a payment to come. For life. For Moiraine.

ən i wəɾ əv tə peɪ ɪt. ɪn ðət moʊmənt, hi nu ðəɾ i wʊd. fəɹ i nu ðəɾ ɪf i dɪd nɑt, ðə kɑst wəd bi tu ɡɹeɪt. nɑt dʒʌs tə tɑm, nɑt dʒʌs tə mɔɪɹeɪn, ən nɑt dʒʌs tə mæt hɪmsɛlf.

And he would have to pay it. In that moment, he knew that he would. For he knew that if he did not, the cost would be too great. Not just to Thom, not just to Moiraine, and not just to Mat himself.

baɪ wʌt hid bɪn toʊld, ðə feɪɾ ə ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn ðɪs moʊmənt.

By what he'd been told, the fate of the world itself depended on this moment.

wɛl bɝn mi fəɹ ə ful, mæt θɔt. meɪbi aɪm ə hɪɹoʊ æftɝ ɔl. dɪdn ðət biɾ ɔl?

Well burn me for a fool, Mat thought. Maybe I am a hero after all. Didn't that beat all?

"aɪl peɪ ɪt," mæt ənaʊnst. "hæf ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝld." tə seɪv ðə wɝld.

"I'll pay it," Mat announced. "Half the light of the world." To save the world.

"dʌn!" wʌn ə ðə meɪl ɛlfɪn ənaʊnst.

"Done!" one of the male Eelfinn announced.

ði eɪt kɹitʃɝz lɛpt - əz ɪf wʌn - fɹəm ðɛɹ pɛɾəstəlz. ðeɪ ɛnkloʊzd ɪm ɪn ə taɪɾənɪŋ sɝkəl, laɪk ə nus. kwɪk, sʌpəl ən pɹɛɾətɔɹi.

The eight creatures leaped - as if one - from their pedestals. They enclosed him in a tightening circle, like a noose. Quick, supple and predatory.

"mæt!" tɑm kɹaɪd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə hoʊl ði ʌnkɑnʃəs mɔɪɹeɪn waɪl ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ wʌn ə hɪz naɪvz.

"Mat!" Thom cried, struggling to hold the unconscious Moiraine while reaching for one of his knives.

mæt hɛld ʌp ə hæn təwɔɹd tɑm ən noʊl. "ðɪs mʌs bi dʌn," hi sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə fju stɛps əweɪ fɹəm ɪz fɹɛnz. ði ɛlfɪn pæst əm wɪθaʊt spɛɹɪŋ ə ɡlæns. ðə ɡoʊl stʌdz ɑn ðə stʃɹæps kɹɔsɪŋ ðə meɪl ɛlfɪnz tʃɛsts ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ðə jɛloʊ laɪt. ɔl eɪt kɹitʃɝz wɝ smaɪlɪŋ waɪd.

Mat held up a hand toward Thom and Noal. "This must be done," he said, taking a few steps away from his friends. The Eelfinn passed them without sparing a glance. The gold studs on the straps crossing the male Eelfinn's chests glittered in the yellow light. All eight creatures were smiling wide.

noʊl ɹeɪzd ɪz sɔɹd.

Noal raised his sword.

"noʊ!" mæt jɛld. "doʊn bɹeɪk ðɪs əɡɹimənt. ɪf jə du, wi ɔl wɪl daɪ hɪɹ!"

"No!" Mat yelled. "Don't break this agreement. If you do, we all will die here!"

ði ɛlfɪn stɛpt ʌp ɪn ə taɪt sɝkəl ɝaʊn mæt. hi tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk əɾ əm ɔl ət wʌns, hɑɹt θəɾɪŋ laʊɾɝ ən laʊɾɝ ɪn ɪz tʃɛst. ðeɪ wɝ snɪfɪŋ əɾ ɪm əɡɛn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪn dip bɹɛθs, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ dʒɹu fɹəm hɪm.

The Eelfinn stepped up in a tight circle around Mat. He tried to look at them all at once, heart thudding louder and louder in his chest. They were sniffing at him again, drawing in deep breaths, enjoying whatever it was they drew from him.

"du ɪt, bɝn ju," mæt ɡɹaʊld. "bʌt noʊ ðɪs ɪz ðə læs jəl ɡɛɾ ə mi. əl ɪskeɪp jəɹ taʊɝ, ən əl faɪn ə weɪ tə fɹi maɪ maɪn fɹəm jə fɝɛvɝ. jə woʊn əv mi. meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɪz nɑt jəɹ blʌɾi pʌpət."

"Do it, burn you," Mat growled. "But know this is the last you'll get of me. I'll escape your tower, and I'll find a way to free my mind from you forever. You won't have me. Matrim Cauthon is not your bloody puppet."

"wi ʃæl si," ən ɛlfɪn meɪl ɡɹaʊld, aɪz lʌsfəl. ðə kɹitʃɝz hæn snæp fɔɹwɝd, tu- ʃɑɹp neɪlz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt. hi dʒɹoʊv əm dɝɛkli ɪndə ðə sɑkəɾ ɝaʊn mæts lɛft aɪ, ðən ɹɪp ði aɪ aʊt wɪð ə snæp.

"We shall see," an Eelfinn male growled, eyes lustful. The creature's hand snapped forward, too- sharp nails glittering in the dim light. He drove them directly into the socket around Mat's left eye, then ripped the eye out with a snap.

mæt skɹimd. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt hɝt! mɔɹ ðən ɛni waʊn teɪkən ɪn bæɾəl, mɔɹ ðən ɛni ɪnsəlt əɹ bɑɹb. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðə kɹitʃɝ hæd pɹɛst ɪts dəsitfəl klɔz ɪndə hɪz maɪn ən soʊl.

Mat screamed. Light, but it hurt! More than any wound taken in battle, more than any insult or barb. It was as if the creature had pressed its deceitful claws into his mind and soul.

mæt fɛl tə hɪz niz, spɪɹ klæɾɝɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn əz i ɹeɪz hænz tə hɪz feɪs. hi fɛl slɪknəs ɑn ɪz tʃik, ən i skɹimd əɡɛn əz ɪz fɪŋɡɝz fɛl ði ɛmpti hoʊl wɛɹ ɪz aɪ hæd bɪn.

Mat fell to his knees, spear clattering to the ground as he raised hands to his face. He felt slickness on his cheek, and he screamed again as his fingers felt the empty hole where his eye had been.

hi θɹu hɪz hɛd bæk ən jɛld ɪndə ðə ɹum, bɛloʊɪŋ ɪn æɡəni.

He threw his head back and yelled into the room, bellowing in agony.

ɛlfɪn wɑtʃt wɪð ðɛɹ hɔɹəd, ɔlmoʊst-hjumən feɪsəz, aɪz nɛɹoʊɾ ɪn ɛkstəsi əz ðeɪ fɛɾ ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm mæt, ən ɔlmoʊst ɪnvɪzəbəl veɪpɝ ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪt.

Eelfinn watched with their horrid, almost-human faces, eyes narrowed in ecstasy as they fed on something rising from Mat, An almost invisible vapor of red and white.

"ðə seɪvɝ!" wʌn ɛlfɪn ɪkskleɪmd.

"The savor!" one Eelfinn exclaimed.

"soʊ lɔŋ!" kɹaɪɾ ənʌðɝ.

"So long!" cried another.

"haʊ ɪt twɪsts ɝaʊn hɪm!" sɛd ðə wʌn u hæd teɪkən ɪz aɪ. "haʊ ɪt spɪnz! sɛns ə blʌɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ! ən ðə ɡæmblɝ bɪkʌmz ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɔl! aɪ kən teɪs feɪɾ ɪtsɛlf!"

"How it twists around him!" said the one who had taken his eye. "How it spins! Scents of blood in the air! And the gambler becomes the center of all! I can taste fate itself!"

mæt haʊld, hɪz hæt fɔlɪŋ bæk əz i lʊk θɹu ə sɪŋɡəl, tɛɹ-mʌɾəld aɪ təwɔɹd ðə dɑɹknəs əbʌv. hɪz aɪ sɑkət sim tə bi ɑn faɪɝ! bleɪzɪŋ! hi fɛl ðə blʌɾ ən sɪɹə dʒɹaɪ ɑn ɪz feɪs, ðən fleɪk əweɪ əz i skɹimd. ði ɛlfɪn dʒɹu ɪn dipɝ bɹɛθs, lʊkɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk.

Mat howled, his hat falling back as he looked through a single, tear-muddled eye toward the darkness above. His eye socket seemed to be on fire! Blazing! He felt the blood and sera dry on his face, then flake away as he screamed. The Eelfinn drew in deeper breaths, looking drunk.

mæt lɛɾ aʊt wʌn faɪnəl skɹim. ðən i klɛntʃt ɪz fɪsts ən ʃʌɾ ɪz dʒɔ, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt stɑp ə loʊ ɡɹoʊn - ə ɡɹaʊl ʌv æŋɡɝ ən peɪn -  fɹəm saʊndɪŋ dip wɪðɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. wʌn ə ði ɛlfɪn meɪlz kəlæpst, əz ɪf oʊvɝwɛlmd. hi wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd teɪkən mæts aɪ. hi klʌtʃt ɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, kɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪt. ði ʌðɝz stʌmbəld əweɪ, faɪndɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ tə pɪlɝz əɹ ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹum, ɹɛstɪŋ əɡɛnst əm fəɹ səpɔɹt.

Mat let out one final scream. Then he clenched his fists and shut his jaw, though he could not stop a low groan - a growl of anger and pain -  from sounding deep within his throat. One of the Eelfinn males collapsed, as if overwhelmed. He was the one who had taken Mat's eye. He clutched it in his hands, curling around it. The others stumbled away, finding their way to pillars or the sides of the room, resting against them for support.

noʊl dæʃt tə mæts saɪd, θɔɹn fɑloʊɪŋ mɔɹ kɛɹfəli, stɪl kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn.

Noal dashed to Mat's side, Thorn following more carefully, still cradling Moiraine.

"mæt?" noʊl æskt.

"Mat?" Noal asked.

tiθ stɪl klɛntʃt əɡɛns ðə peɪn, mæt fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə ɹitʃ bæk ən snætʃ ɪz hæɾ ɔf ðə waɪt flɔɹ. hi wɑz nɑt livɪŋ ɪz hæt, bɝn hɪm. ɪt wɑz ə blʌɾi ɡʊd hæt.

Teeth still clenched against the pain, Mat forced himself to reach back and snatch his hat off the white floor. He was not leaving his hat, burn him. It was a bloody good hat.

hi stʌmbəl tə hɪz fit.

He stumbled to his feet.

"jɔɹ aɪ, mæt . . ." θɔɹn sɛd.

"Your eye, Mat . . ." Thorn said.

"dʌzn mæɾɝ," mæt sɛd. bɝn mi fəɹ ə ful. ə blʌɾi, ɡoʊt-hɛɾəd ful. hi kəd bɛɹli θɪŋk θɹu ði æɡəni.

"Doesn't matter," Mat said. Burn me for a fool. A bloody, goat-headed fool. He could barely think through the agony.

hɪz ʌðɝ aɪ blɪŋk tɪɹz ə peɪn. ɪt ɹɪli dɪd sim i hæd lɔs hæf ə ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝld. ɪt wɑz laɪk lʊkɪŋ θɹu ə wɪndoʊ wɪð wʌn hæf blækənd. dɪspaɪt ðə bleɪzɪŋ peɪn ɪn ɪz lɛf sɑkət, hi fɛlt əz i ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə oʊpən ɪz aɪ.

His other eye blinked tears of pain. It really did seem he had lost half of the light of the world. It was like looking through a window with one half blackened. Despite the blazing pain in his left socket, he felt as he should be able to open his eye.

bʌɾ i kəd nɑt. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. ən noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃænəlɪŋ kəd ɹipleɪs ðæt.

But he could not. It was gone. And no Aes Sedai channeling could replace that.

hi pʊld ɑn ɪz hæt, dɪfaɪənli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə peɪn. hi pʊl ðə bɹɪm daʊn ɑn ðə lɛft, ʃeɪɾɪŋ ði ɛmpti sɑkət, ðən bɛn daʊn ən pɪkt ʌp ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, stʌmbəlɪŋ bʌt mænɪdʒɪŋ ɪt.

He pulled on his hat, defiantly ignoring the pain. He pulled the brim down on the left, shading the empty socket, then bent down and picked up his ashandarei, stumbling but managing it.

"aɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn ðə wʌn tə peɪ," θɔɹn sɛd, vɔɪs bɪɾɝ. "nɑt ju, mæt. jə dɪdn ivən wɑnə kʌm."

"I should have been the one to pay," Thorn said, voice bitter. "Not you, Mat. You didn't even want to come."

"ɪt wɑz maɪ tʃɔɪs," mæt sɛd. "æn aɪ hæd tə də ɪt, ɛniweɪ. ɪts wʌn ə ði ænsɝz aɪ wɑz toʊl baɪ ði æɛlfɪn wən aɪ fɝs keɪm. aɪɾ əv tə ɡɪv ʌp hæf ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝl tə seɪv ðə wɝld. blʌɾi sneɪks."

"It was my choice," Mat said. "And I had to do it, anyway. It's one of the answers I was told by the Aelfinn when I first came. I'd have to give up half the light of the world to save the world. Bloody snakes."

"tə seɪv ðə wɝld?" θɔɹn æskt, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət mɔɪɹeɪnz pisfəl feɪs, hɝ bɑɾi ɹæpt ɪn ðə pætʃwɝk kloʊk. hi hæd lɛft ɪz pæk ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

"To save the world?" Thorn asked, looking down at Moiraine's peaceful face, her body wrapped in the patchwork cloak. He had left his pack on the floor.

"ʃi hæz sʌmθɪŋ jɛt tə du," mæt sɛd. ðə peɪn wɑz ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ sʌmwʌt. "wi nid hɝ, θɔɹn.

"She has something yet to do," Mat said. The pain was retreating somewhat. "We need her, Thorn.

bɝn mi, bʌɾ ɪts pɹɑbli sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɹænd. ɛniweɪ, ðɪs hæd tə hæpən."

Burn me, but it's probably something to do with Rand. Anyway, this had to happen."

"æn ɪf ɪt hædnt?" θɔɹn æskt. "ʃi sɛd ʃi sɔ . . ."

"And if it hadn't?" Thorn asked. "She said she saw . . ."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹweɪ. ði ɛlfɪn wɝ stɪl oʊvɝwɛlmd.

"It doesn't matter," Mat said, turning toward the doorway. The Eelfinn were still overwhelmed.

wʌn wəd θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðə wʌnz tə luz ən aɪ, lʊkɪŋ ət ðoʊz ɪkspɹɛʃənz! mæt sɛɾ ɪz pæk ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, livɪŋ θɔɹnz wɛɹ ɪt sæt. hi kəd nɑt kæɹi tu, nɑɾ ən bi eɪbəl tə faɪt.

One would think they had been the ones to lose an eye, looking at those expressions! Mat set his pack on his shoulder, leaving Thorn's where it sat. He could not carry two, not and be able to fight.

"naʊ aɪv sin sʌmθɪŋ," noʊl sɛd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹum ən ɪts ɑkjəpəns. "sʌmθɪŋ noʊ mæn əz ɛvɝ sin, aɪ wɔɹənt. ʃəd wi kɪl ðɛm?"

"Now I've seen something," Noal said, looking over the room and its occupants. "Something no man has ever seen, I warrant. Should we kill them?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "maɪt bɹeɪk əɹ bɑɹɡən."

Mat shook his head. "Might break our bargain."

"wɪl ðeɪ kip ɪt?" tɑm æskt.

"Will they keep it?" Thom asked.

"nɑɾ ɪf ðeɪ kən wɪɡəl aʊɾ ʌv ɪt," mæt sɛd, ðən wɪnst əɡɛn. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪz hɛd hɝt! wɛl, hi kəd nɑt sɪɾ ɝaʊn ən kɹaɪ laɪk i hæd lɔst ɪz feɪvɹɪt foʊl. "lɛts ɡoʊ."

"Not if they can wiggle out of it," Mat said, then winced again. Light, but his head hurt! Well, he could not sit around and cry like he had lost his favorite foal. "Let's go."

ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl. noʊl kæɹiɾ ə tɔɹtʃ, ðoʊ hi hæd ɹɪlʌktənli lɛft ɪz stæf bɪhaɪnd, feɪvɝɪŋ ɪz ʃɔɹtsɔɝd.

They made their way out of the grand hall. Noal carried a torch, though he had reluctantly left his staff behind, favoring his shortsword.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ oʊpənɪŋz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ ðɪs taɪm, ən mæt hɝd noʊl mʌɾɝɪŋ ət ðæt. ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt.

There were no openings in the hallway this time, and Mat heard Noal muttering at that. It felt right.

hi hæd dɪmændəɾ ə stʃɹeɪt pæθweɪ bæk. ði ɛlfɪn wɝ laɪɝz ən tʃits, bʌt ðeɪ sim tə bi laɪɝz ən tʃits laɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. mæt hæd meɪɾ ɪz dɪmænz kɛɹfəli ðɪs taɪm, ɹæðɝ ðən spaʊɾɪŋ aʊt wʌtɛvɝ əkɝd tə hɪm.

He had demanded a straight pathway back. The Eelfinn were liars and cheats, but they seemed to be liars and cheats like the Aes Sedai. Mat had made his demands carefully this time, rather than spouting out whatever occurred to him.

ðə hɔlweɪ wɛn ɑn fəɹ ə lɔŋ waɪl. noʊl wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ nɝvəs; mæt kɛpt ɑn fɔɹwɝd, fʊtstɛps ɪn taɪm wɪð ɪz θɹɑbɪŋ skʌl. haʊ wəd mɪsɪŋ ən aɪ tʃeɪnʒ haʊ hi fɔt?

The hallway went on for a long while. Noal was growing more and more nervous; Mat kept on forward, footsteps in time with his throbbing skull. How would missing an eye change how he fought?

hi wəɾ əv tə bi mɔɹ kɛɹfəl ə ðət lɛf saɪd. ən i wəɾ əv tʃɹʌbəl dʒʌdʒɪŋ dɪstəns naʊ.

He would have to be more careful of that left side. And he would have trouble judging distance now.

ɪn fækt, hi hæd ðət tʃɹʌbəl naʊ - wɔlz ən flɔɹ wɝ dɪstɝbɪŋli hɑɹd tə dʒʌdʒ.

In fact, he had that trouble now - walls and floor were disturbingly hard to judge.

tɑm klʌtʃt mɔɪɹeɪn kloʊs tə hɪz tʃɛst, laɪk ə maɪzɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɪz ɡoʊld. wʌt wɑz ʃi tə hɪm, ɛniweɪ? mæt hæɾ əsum ðət tɑm wɑz əlɔŋ fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən ðət mæt wɑz - kəz ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt niɾəd tə bi dʌn. ðət tɛndɝnəs ɪn θɔɹnz feɪs wɑz nɑt wʌt mæt hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə si.

Thom clutched Moiraine close to his chest, like a miser holding his gold. What was she to him, anyway? Mat had assumed that Thom was along for the same reason that Mat was - because it felt as if it needed to be done. That tenderness in Thorn's face was not what Mat had expected to see.

ðə hɔlweɪ ɛndəɾ əbɹʌpli ɪn ə faɪv-saɪɾəd ɑɹtʃ. ðə ɹum bɪɑn əpɪɹd tə bi ðə wʌn wɪð ðə mɛltəd slæɡ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. noʊ saɪnz ə ðə faɪt bɪfɔɹ wɝ vɪzəbəl, noʊ blʌɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

The hallway ended abruptly in a five-sided arch. The room beyond appeared to be the one with the melted slag on the floor. No signs of the fight before were visible, no blood on the floor.

mæt tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən lɛd ðə weɪ θɹu. hi tɛnst əz i sɔ ɛlfɪn hɪɹ, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ əɹ stændɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, hɪsɪŋ ən ɡɹoʊlɪŋ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt muv, dɪd nɑt stʃɹaɪk, ðoʊ səm jɪp kwaɪətli. ʃædoʊz meɪɾ əm sim ivən mɔɹ laɪk fɑksəz. ɪf mæt lʊkt ɹaɪɾ ət wʌn, hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs mɪsteɪk əm fəɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɛn ən wɪmən, bʌt ðə weɪ ðeɪ muvd ɪn dɑɹknəs, səmtaɪmz ɑn ɔl fɔɹz . . . noʊ mæn wɔk laɪk ðæt, wɪð ði æŋkʃəs tɛnʃən ʌv ə tʃeɪn pɹɛɾətɝ. laɪk ən æŋɡɹi haʊnd, sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm jə baɪ ə fɛns ən fɪɹsli iɡɝ tə ɡɛt tə jəɹ θɹoʊt.

Mat took a deep breath and led the way through. He tensed as he saw Eelfinn here, crouching or standing in the shadows, hissing and growling. They did not move, did not strike, though some yipped quietly. Shadows made them seem even more like foxes. If Mat looked right at one, he could almost mistake them for ordinary men and women, but the way they moved in darkness, sometimes on all fours . . . No man walked like that, with the anxious tension of a chained predator. Like an angry hound, separated from you by a fence and fiercely eager to get to your throat.

bʌt ðeɪ hɛl tə ðɛɹ bɑɹɡən. nʌn ətækt, ən mæt bɪɡæn tə fil ɹaɪt ɡʊɾ əbaʊt hɪmsɛlf wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. hi hæd biɾən ðɛm. læs taɪm, ðeɪ hæd ɡɑɾən ðə bɛɾɝ ɛnd, bʌt ðət wɑz oʊnli kəz ðeɪ hæd fɔt laɪk kaʊɝdz, pʌntʃɪŋ ə mæn u dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə faɪt hæd stɑɹɾəd.

But they held to their bargain. None attacked, and Mat began to feel right good about himself once they reached the other side of the room. He had beaten them. Last time, they had gotten the better end, but that was only because they had fought like cowards, punching a man who did not know the fight had started.

ðɪs taɪm i hæd bɪn ɹɛɾi. hi hæd ʃoʊn əm ðət meɪtʃɹim koʊ-θɑn wɑz noʊ ful.

This time he had been ready. He had shown them that Matrim Cau-thon was no fool.

ðeɪ ɛntɝɾ ə kɔɹəɾɝ wɪð ðə feɪnli ɡloʊɪŋ waɪt stim ət ðə tɑp. ðə flɔɹ wɑz ə ðoʊz blæk, ɪntɝlɑkɪŋ tʃɹaɪæŋɡəlz, kɝvd ɑn ðə saɪdz laɪk skeɪlz. mæt bɪɡæn tə bɹið iziɝ əz ðeɪ ɛntɝd wʌn ə ðə ɹumz wɪð ðə twɪstɪŋ stim ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝz, ðoʊ hɪz aɪ sɑkət stɪl hɝt laɪk ðə nɛðɝz ʌv ə fɹɛʃli ɡɛldɪd stæljən.

They entered a corridor with the faintly glowing white steam at the top. The floor was of those black, interlocking triangles, curved on the sides like scales. Mat began to breathe easier as they entered one of the rooms with the twisting steam rising from the corners, though his eye socket still hurt like the nethers of a freshly gelded stallion.

hi stɑpt ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum, bʌt ðən kəntɪnjud fɔɹwɝd. hi hæd dɪmændəɾ ə stʃɹeɪt pæθweɪ. ðət wɑz wʌɾ i wəd ɡɛt. noʊ dʌbəlɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ ðɪs taɪm. "blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" mæt sɛd, ɹilaɪzɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ əz i wɔkt.

He stopped in the center of the room, but then continued forward. He had demanded a straight pathway. That was what he would get. No doubling back and forth this time. "Blood and bloody ashes!" Mat said, realizing something as he walked.

"wʌt?" θɔɹn æskt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð əlɑɹm.

"What?" Thorn asked, looking up from Moiraine with alarm.

"maɪ daɪs," mæt sɛd. "aɪ ʃʊɾə ɪnkluɾəd ɡɛɾɪŋ maɪ daɪs bæk ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən."

"My dice," Mat said. "I should have included getting my dice back in the bargain."

"bʌt wi dɪskʌvɝd jə doʊnt niɾ əm tə ɡaɪɾ ʌs."

"But we discovered you don't need them to guide us."

"ɪts nɑɾ əbaʊt ðæt," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld. "aɪ laɪk ðoʊz daɪs." hi pʊld ɪz hæt daʊn əɡɛn, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ əhɛd. wɑz ðət moʊʃən i sɔ? ɔl ðə weɪ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ə ɡʊd dʌzən ɹumz əweɪ? noʊ, ɪt mʌs bi ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə ʃædoʊz ən ðə ʃɪftɪŋ stim.

"It's not about that," Mat grumbled. "I like those dice." He pulled his hat down again, looking down the hallway ahead. Was that motion he saw? All the way in the distance, a good dozen rooms away? No, it must be a trick of the shadows and the shifting steam.

"mæt," noʊl sɛd. "aɪv mɛnʃən ðət maɪ oʊl tʌŋ ɪzənt wʌɾ ɪt wʌns wɑz. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ ʌndɝstʊd wʌt jə sɛd. ðə bɑɹɡən jə meɪd."

"Mat," Noal said. "I've mentioned that my Old Tongue isn't what it once was. But I think I understood what you said. The bargain you made."

"jɛs?" mæt sɛd, oʊnli hæf-lɪsnɪŋ. hæɾ i bɪn spikɪŋ ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ əɡɛn? bɝn hɪm.

"Yes?" Mat said, only half-listening. Had he been speaking in the Old Tongue again? Burn him.

ən wʌt wɑz ðət daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ?

And what was that down the hallway?

"wɛl," noʊl sɛd, "ju sɛd - əz pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən - sʌmθɪŋ laɪk 'ju fɑksəz kænt nɑk əs daʊn əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl əs əɹ ɛniθɪŋ.' "

"Well," Noal said, "you said - as part of the bargain - something like 'you foxes can't knock us down or try to kill us or anything.' "

"ʃʊɹ dɪd," mæt sɛd.

"Sure did," Mat said.

"ju sɛd fɑksəz, mæt," noʊl sɛd. "ðə fɑksəz kæn hɝɾ ʌs."

"You said foxes, Mat," Noal said. "The foxes can't hurt us."

"æn ðeɪ lɛɾ əs pæs."

"And they let us pass."

"bʌt wʌɾ əbaʊt ði ʌðɝz?" noʊl æskt. "ði æɛlfɪn? ɪf ði ɛlfɪn kæn hɝɾ ʌs, ɑɹ ði æɛlfɪn ɹikwaɪɝd tə liv əs bi əz wɛl?"

"But what about the others?" Noal asked. "The Aelfinn? If the Eelfinn can't hurt us, are the Aelfinn required to leave us be as well?"

ðə ʃædoʊz ɪn ðə fɑɹ-dɪstən kɔɹəɾɝ ɹizɑlvd ɪndə fɪɡjɝz kæɹiɪŋ lɔŋ, sɪnwəs bɹɑnz sɔɹdz wɪð kɝvɪŋ bleɪdz. tɔl fɪɡjɝz, wɛɹɪŋ leɪɝz ə jɛloʊ klɔθ, ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz stʃɹeɪɾ ən blæk. dʌzənz ə ðɛm, hu muvd wɪð ən ənnætʃɹəl ɡɹeɪs, aɪz stɛɹɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. aɪz wɪð pjupəlz ðət wɝ vɝɾɪkəl slɪts.

The shadows in the far-distant corridor resolved into figures carrying long, sinuous bronze swords with curving blades. Tall figures, wearing layers of yellow cloth, the hair on their heads straight and black. Dozens of them, who moved with an unnatural grace, eyes staring forward. Eyes with pupils that were vertical slits.

blʌɾi ən blʌɾi æʃəz!

Bloody and bloody ashes!

"ɹʌn!" mæt jɛld.

"Run!" Mat yelled.

"wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən?" noʊl æskt, əlɑɹmd.

"Which direction?" Noal asked, alarmed.

"ɛni dɝɛkʃən!" mæt jɛld. "soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪts əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm!"

"Any direction!" Mat yelled. "So long as it's away from them!"


tʃæptɝ fɪftifaɪv


CHAPTER 55

ðə wʌn lɛf bɪhaɪnd


The One Left Behind

əlaʊd bum ʃʊk ðə hɔlweɪz, meɪkɪŋ ði ɪntaɪɝ stʃɹʌktʃɝ ɹʌmbəl. mæt stʌmbəld, linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl fəɹ səpɔɹɾ əz smoʊk ən tʃɪps ə ɹɑk spɹeɪɾ aʊɾ ə ði oʊpənɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

Aloud boom shook the hallways, making the entire structure rumble. Mat stumbled, leaning against the wall for support as smoke and chips of rock sprayed out of the opening behind them.

hi dʌkt ɪz hɛɾ ɝaʊn ən lʊk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ əz θɔɹn ən noʊl ɹæn ɔnwɝd, θɔɹn klʌtʃɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn. noʊl hæd tɔst ɪz tɔɹtʃ əsaɪɾ ən ɡɑɾən aʊɾ ə dʒɹʌm tə tʃɹaɪ tə suð ði æɛlfɪn.

He ducked his head around and looked down the hallway as Thorn and Noal ran onward, Thorn clutching Moiraine. Noal had tossed his torch aside and gotten out a drum to try to soothe the Aelfinn.

ðət hæd nɑt wɝkt, ən soʊ mæt hæd tɝn tə ði ɪksploʊɾɪŋ sɪləndɝz ən naɪtfloʊɝz.

That had not worked, and so Mat had turned to the exploding cylinders and nightflowers.

laɪt, bʌt ðə sɪləndɝz wɝ dɛdli! hi sɔ kɔɹpsəz ʌv æɛlfɪn laɪɪŋ skæɾɝd θɹu ðə hɔlweɪ, ðɛɹ ɡlɪsnɪŋ skɪn ɹɪpt ən tɔɹn, ivəl-lʊkɪŋ smoʊk stimɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ blʌd. ʌðɝz slɪɾ aʊɾ ə dɔɹweɪz ən ælkoʊvz, pʊʃɪŋ θɹu ðə smoʊk. ðeɪ wɔkt ɑn tu lɛɡz, bʌt ðeɪ sim tə slaɪðɝ əz ðeɪ wɔkt, weɪvɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu ðə hɔlweɪ, ðɛɹ hɪsɪŋ ɡɹoʊɪŋ æŋɡɹiɝ ən æŋɡɹiɝ.

Light, but the cylinders were deadly! He saw corpses of Aelfinn lying scattered through the hallway, their glistening skin ripped and torn, evil-looking smoke steaming from their blood. Others slid out of doorways and alcoves, pushing through the smoke. They walked on two legs, but they seemed to slither as they walked, waving back and forth through the hallway, their hissing growing angrier and angrier.

hɑɹt paʊndɪŋ, mæt tʃɑɹdʒd æftɝ mæt ən noʊl. "ðeɪ stɪl fɑloʊɪŋ?" noʊl kɔld.

Heart pounding, Mat charged after Mat and Noal. "They still following?" Noal called.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk?" mæt sɛd, kætʃɪŋ ʌp tə ði ʌðɝ tu. "laɪt, bʌt ðoʊz sneɪks ɑɹ fæsti"

"What do you think?" Mat said, catching up to the other two. "Light, but those snakes are fasti"

mæt ən ði ʌðɝ tu bɝst ɪndə ənʌðɝ ɹum, aɪdɛntɪkəl tə ɔl ə ði ʌðɝz. veɪɡli ɔf-skeɪl skwɛɹ wɔlz, stim ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝz, blæk tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl-pæɾɝn flɔɹ taɪlz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ oʊpənɪŋ ət ðə sɛntɝ tə ɡɛɾ əm aʊt. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz.

Mat and the other two burst into another room, identical to all of the others. Vaguely off-scale square walls, steam rising from the corners, black triangle-pattern floor tiles. There was no triangular opening at the center to get them out. Blood and bloody ashes.

mæt ɡlænst ət ðə θɹi weɪz aʊt, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn swɛɾi hænz. ðeɪ kəd nɑt də ðə seɪm tʃɹɪk əz bɪfɔɹ, baʊnsɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ bɪtwin ðə seɪm tu ɹumz. nɑt wɪð ði æɛlfɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm. hi niɾəd tə ɪnvoʊk ɪz lʌk. hi pɹipɛɹd tə spɪn, ən -  "wi hæv tə kip muvɪŋ!" noʊl jɛld. hi hæd stɑp baɪ ðə dɔɹweɪ, dænsɪŋ fɹəm wʌn toʊ tə ðə nɛkst ɪn æŋzaɪəɾi. "mæt! ɪf ðoʊz sneɪks kætʃ əs . . ."

Mat glanced at the three ways out, holding his ashandarei in sweaty hands. They could not do the same trick as before, bouncing back and forth between the same two rooms. Not with the Aelfinn behind them. He needed to invoke his luck. He prepared to spin, and -  "We have to keep moving!" Noal yelled. He had stopped by the doorway, dancing from one toe to the next in anxiety. "Mat! If those snakes catch us . . ."

mæt kəd hɪɹ əm bɪhaɪnd, hɪsɪŋ. laɪk ðə ɹʌʃ ʌv ə ɹɪvɝ. hi pɪkt ə dɝɛkʃən ən ɹæn.

Mat could hear them behind, hissing. Like the rush of a river. He picked a direction and ran.

"θɹoʊ ənʌðɝ sɪləndɝ!" θɔɹn sɛd.

"Throw another cylinder!" Thorn said.

"ðæt wɑz ðə læst wʌn!" mæt sɛd. "ænd wiv oʊnli ɡɑt θɹi naɪt-flaʊɝz." hɪz pæk wɑz filɪŋ laɪt.

"That was the last one!" Mat said. "And we've only got three night-flowers." His pack was feeling light.

"mjuzɪk dʌznt wɝk ɑn ðɛm," noʊl sɛd, θɹoʊɪŋ əsaɪɾ ɪz dʒɹʌm. "ðeɪɹ tu æŋɡɹi."

"Music doesn't work on them," Noal said, throwing aside his drum. "They're too angry."

mæt kɝst ən lɪɾ ə naɪtfloʊɝ wɪð ə stʃɹaɪkɝ, ðən tɔst ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə θɹi ʌv əm bæɹəld ɪndə ənʌðɝ ɹum, ðən kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn dɝɛkli θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd.

Mat cursed and lit a nightflower with a striker, then tossed it over his shoulder. The three of them barreled into another room, then continued on directly through the doorway on the other side.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt weɪ tə ɡoʊ, læd," θɔɹn sɛd. hi saʊndəd soʊ wɪndɪd! "wɝ lɔst."

"I don't know what way to go, lad," Thorn said. He sounded so winded! "We're lost."

"aɪv bɪn pɪkɪŋ dɝɛkʃənz ət ɹændəm!" mæt sɛd.

"I've been picking directions at random!" Mat said.

"oʊnli jə kænt ɡoʊ bækwɝd," θɔɹn sɛd. "ðæts pɹɑbli ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə lʌk wɑns əs tə ɡoʊ!"

"Only you can't go backward," Thorn said. "That's probably the direction the luck wants us to go!"

ðə naɪtfloʊɝ bumd, ði ɪksploʊʒən ɛkoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz. ɪt wɑz nɑt nɪɹli əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ðəɾ ə ðə sɪləndɝz. mæt ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, siɪŋ smoʊk ən spɑɹks flaɪ θɹu ðə tʌnəl. ðə faɪɝ sloʊd ði æɛlfɪn, bʌt sun ðə mɔɹ dɛɹɪŋ mɛmbɝz ə ðə bæn slaɪðɝd θɹu ðə smoʊk.

The nightflower boomed, the explosion echoing through the corridors. It was not nearly as great as that of the cylinders. Mat risked a glance over his shoulder, seeing smoke and sparks fly through the tunnel. The fire slowed the Aelfinn, but soon the more daring members of the band slithered through the smoke.

"meɪbi wi kən nəɡoʊʃieɪt!" θɔɹn pæntɪd.

"Maybe we can negotiate!" Thorn panted.

"ðeɪ lʊk tu æŋɡɹi!" noʊl sɛd.

"They look too angry!" Noal said.

"mæt," θɔɹn sɛd, "ju mɛnʃən ðət ðeɪ nu əbaʊt jəɹ aɪ. ðeɪ ænsɝɾ ə kwɛstʃən əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"Mat," Thorn said, "you mentioned that they knew about your eye. They answered a question about it."

"ðeɪ toʊl mi aɪd blʌɾi ɡɪv ʌp hæf ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝld," mæt sɛd, skʌl stɪl θɹɑbɪŋ. "aɪ dɪdnt wɑnə noʊ, bʌt ðeɪ toʊl mi ɛniweɪ."

"They told me I'd bloody give up half the light of the world," Mat said, skull still throbbing. "I didn't want to know, but they told me anyway."

"wʌɾ ɛls dɪd ðeɪ seɪ?" θɔɹn æskt. "ɛniθɪŋ ðət kən bi ə klu? haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛɾ aʊt læs taɪm?"

"What else did they say?" Thorn asked. "Anything that can be a clue? How did you get out last time?"

"ðeɪ θɹu mi aʊt," mæt sɛd.

"They threw me out," Mat said.

hi ən ði ʌðɝz bɝst ɪndə ənʌðɝ ɹum - noʊ dɔɹweɪ - ðən dæʃt aʊt ðə lɛft-hæn ɛɡzɪt. wʌt θɔɹn hæd sɛd bɪfɔɹ wɑz kɝɛkt. ðeɪ pɹɑbli niɾəd tə dʌbəl bæk. bʌt ðeɪ kəd nɑt, nɑt wɪð ðət nɛst ə vaɪpɝz fɑloʊɪŋ soʊ kloʊsli!

He and the others burst into another room - no doorway - then dashed out the left-hand exit. What Thorn had said before was correct. They probably needed to double back. But they could not, not with that nest of vipers following so closely!

"ðeɪ θɹu mi aʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm ɪn ði æɛlfɪn ɹɛlm," mæt sɛd, filɪŋ wɪndɪd. "ɪt lidz tə ðə beɪsmən ə ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ."

"They threw me out of the doorframe in the Aelfinn realm," Mat said, feeling winded. "It leads to the basement of the Stone of Tear."

"ðɛn meɪbi wi kən faɪn ðæt!" tɑm sɛd. "jɔɹ lʌk, mæt. hæv ɪt teɪk əs tə ði æɛlfɪn ɹɛlm."

"Then maybe we can find that!" Thom said. "Your luck, Mat. Have it take us to the Aelfinn realm."

ɪt maɪt wɝk. "ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪ ən spɪnɪŋ əbaʊt.

It might work. "All right," he said, closing his eye and spinning about.

mæt pɔɪntəɾ ɪn ə dɝɛkʃən ən oʊpən ɪz aɪ. hi wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ dɝɛkli təwɔɹd ðə ɡæŋ ʌv æɛlfɪn, wivɪŋ ʌp ðə kɔɹəɾɝ təwɔɹd ðɛm.

Mat pointed in a direction and opened his eye. He was pointing directly toward the gang of Aelfinn, weaving up the corridor toward them.

"blʌɾi æʃəz!" mæt kɝst, tɝnɪŋ ən ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm, pɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ kɔɹəɾɝ ət ɹændəm.

"Bloody ashes!" Mat cursed, turning and running away from them, picking another corridor at random.

tɑm dʒɔɪn hɪm, bʌt wɑz lʊkɪŋ vɛɹi wɪɹid. mæt kəd teɪk mwɑ-ɹeɪn fɹəm ɪm fəɹ ə waɪl, bʌt tɑm wəd bi soʊ taɪɝɾ i wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə faɪt. ði æɛlfɪn wɝ gɑnə ɹʌn əm ɹæɡəd, əz ðeɪ hæd bɝdʒɪt sɛntʃɝiz əɡoʊ.

Thom joined him, but was looking very wearied. Mat could take Moi-raine from him for a while, but Thom would be so tired he would not be able to fight. The Aelfinn were going to run them ragged, as they had Birgitte centuries ago.

ɪn ðə nɛkst ɹum, tɑm stʌmbəl tə ə hɔlt, dʒɹupɪŋ, ðoʊ hi stɪl hɛl mɔɪɹeɪn. laɪk ɔl ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝz, ðɪs wʌn hæd fɔɹ weɪz aʊt. bʌt ði oʊnli weɪ ðət mæɾɝd wɑz wʌn dɝɛkli təwɔɹd ði æɛlfɪn. ðə wʌn ðeɪ kʊdn teɪk.

In the next room, Thom stumbled to a halt, drooping, though he still held Moiraine. Like all of the chambers, this one had four ways out. But the only way that mattered was one directly toward the Aelfinn. The one they couldn't take.

"ðɛɹz noʊ wɪnɪŋ ðɪs ɡeɪm," tɑm sɛd, pæntɪŋ. "ivən ɪf wi tʃit, ðɛɹz noʊ wɪnɪŋ."

"There's no winning this game," Thom said, panting. "Even if we cheat, there's no winning."

"tɑm . . ." mæt sɛɾ ɝdʒənli. hi hændəd tɑm ɪz æsbændʒɹeɪ, ðən pɪkt ʌp mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi wɑz soʊ laɪt. ə ɡʊd θɪŋ, tu, ʌðɝwaɪz tɑm wəd nɛvɝ əv læstəɾ əz lɔŋ əz i hæd.

"Thom . . ." Mat said urgently. He handed Thom his asbandarei, then picked up Moiraine. She was so light. A good thing, too, otherwise Thom would never have lasted as long as he had.

noʊl ɡlænst ət ðɛm, ðən daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. ði æɛlfɪn wəd bi ɑn əm ɪn moʊməns. noʊl mɛt mæts aɪ. "ɡɪv mi jəɹ pæk. aɪ nid ðoʊz naɪtfloʊɝz."

Noal glanced at them, then down the corridor. The Aelfinn would be on them in moments. Noal met Mat's eye. "Give me your pack. I need those nightflowers."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"noʊ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ!" noʊl sɛd. hi dæʃt oʊvɝ ən snæɡd wʌn ə ðə naɪtfloʊɝz. ɪt hæɾ ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt fjuz. hi lɪɾ ɪɾ ən tɔst ɪɾ ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. ði æɛlfɪn wɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf ðət mæt kəd hɪɹ əm skɹim ən hɪs əz ðeɪ sɔ ðə faɪɝwɝk.

"No arguing!" Noal said. He dashed over and snagged one of the nightflowers. It had a very short fuse. He lit it and tossed it into the corridor. The Aelfinn were close enough that Mat could hear them scream and hiss as they saw the firework.

ðə bum keɪm, spɑɹks spɝɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ ən laɪɾɪŋ ðə dɑɹk ɹum. wɛɹ spɑɹks keɪm kloʊs tə wʌn ə ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ kɑləmz ə stim, ðət stim ʃaɪd bæk, dænsɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə fleɪmz. ði ɛɹ smɛl stʃɹɔŋli ʌv smoʊk ən sʌlfɝ. laɪt, hɪz sɑkət wɑz θɹɑbɪŋ əɡɛn.

The boom came, sparks spurting out of the corridor and lighting the dark room. Where sparks came close to one of the rising columns of steam, that steam shied back, dancing away from the flames. The air smelled strongly of smoke and sulphur. Light, his socket was throbbing again.

"naʊ, mæt," noʊl sɛd, mæts ɪɹz stɪl ɹɪŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə blæst, "ɡɪv mi ðə pæk."

"Now, Mat," Noal said, Mat's ears still ringing from the blast, "give me the pack."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" mæt sɛd wɛɹəli əz noʊl tʊk ðə pæk, ðən fɪʃt aʊt ðə læs naɪtfloʊɝ.

"What are you doing?" Mat said warily as Noal took the pack, then fished out the last nightflower.

"ju kən si ɪt, mæt," noʊl sɛd. "wi nid mɔɹ taɪm. juv tə ɡɛt fɑɹ ɪnʌf əhɛɾ ə ðoʊz vaɪpɝz ðət jə kən dʌbəl bæk ə fju taɪmz, lɛt jəɹ lʌk wɝk jə aʊɾ ə ðɪs."

"You can see it, Mat," Noal said. "We need more time. You have to get far enough ahead of those vipers that you can double back a few times, let your luck work you out of this."

noʊl nɑɾəd tə wʌn ə ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz "ðiz kɔɹɪɾɝz ɑɹ nɛɹoʊ. ɡʊd tʃoʊk pɔɪns. ə mæn kəd stæn ðəɹ ən oʊnli hæv tə faɪt wʌn əɹ tu əɾ ə taɪm. hid læs meɪbi ə fju mɪnəts."

Noal nodded to one of the corridors "These corridors are narrow. Good choke points. A man could stand there and only have to fight one or two at a time. He'd last maybe a few minutes."

"noʊl!" tɑm sɛd, wizɪŋ, stændɪŋ wɪð ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz niz nɪɹ mæts æsbændʒɹeɪ linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "ju kæn də ðɪs."

"Noal!" Thom said, wheezing, standing with his hands on his knees near Mat's asbandarei leaning against the wall. "You can't do this."

"jɛs aɪ kæn," noʊl sɛd. hi stɛpt ʌp tə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, bɪɑnd wɪtʃ ði æɛlfɪn ɡæðɝd. "tɑm, jəɹ ɪn noʊ ʃeɪp tə faɪt. mæt, jəɹ ðə wʌn huz lʌk kən faɪn ðə weɪ aʊt. niðɝ ə jə kən steɪ. bʌɾ aɪ kæn."

"Yes I can," Noal said. He stepped up to the corridor, beyond which the Aelfinn gathered. "Thom, you're in no shape to fight. Mat, you're the one whose luck can find the way out. Neither of you can stay. But I can."

"ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ kʌmɪŋ bæk fəɹ ju," mæt sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "æz sun əz wi dʌbəl bæk, ðɪs fleɪmɪŋ pleɪs wɪl teɪk əs sʌmwɛɹ ɛls."

"There will be no coming back for you," Mat said grimly. "As soon as we double back, this flaming place will take us somewhere else."

noʊl mɛɾ ɪz aɪ, ðət wɛðɝd feɪs dɪtɝmənd. "aɪ noʊ. ə pɹaɪs, mæt. wi nu ðɪs pleɪs wəd dɪmæn ə pɹaɪs. wɛl, aɪv sin ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz, dʌn ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz. aɪv bɪn juzd, mæt, wʌn tu mɛni taɪmz. ðɪs ɪz əz ɡʊɾ ə pleɪs əz ɛni tə mit ði ɛnd."

Noal met his eye, that weathered face determined. "I know. A price, Mat. We knew this place would demand a price. Well, I've seen a lot of things, done a lot of things. I've been used, Mat, one too many times. This is as good a place as any to meet the end."

mæt stʊɾ ʌp, lɪftɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn, ðən nɑɾəd ɪn ɹɪspɛk tə noʊl. "kʌm ɑn, tɑm."

Mat stood up, lifting Moiraine, then nodded in respect to Noal. "Come on, Thom."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"kʌm ɑn!" mæt bɑɹkt, dæʃɪŋ tə wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ dɔɹweɪz. tɑm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən kɝst ən dʒɔɪn hɪm, kæɹiɪŋ mæts tɔɹtʃ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ɪz æsbændʒɹeɪ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. noʊl stɛpt ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ bɪhaɪnd, hɛftɪŋ ɪz ʃɔɹts wɝd. ʃeɪps muvd ɪn ðə smoʊk bɪɑn hɪm.

"Come on!" Mat barked, dashing to one of the other doorways. Thom hesitated, then cursed and joined him, carrying Mat's torch in one hand and his asbandarei in the other. Noal stepped into the corridor behind, hefting his shorts word. Shapes moved in the smoke beyond him.

"mæt," noʊl kɔld, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

"Mat," Noal called, glancing over his shoulder.

mæt weɪv tɑm ɑn, bʌt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ bæk.

Mat waved Thom on, but hesitated, looking back.

"ɪf jə ɛvɝ miɾ ə mɔlkɪɹi," noʊl sɛd, "ju tɛl ɪm dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ daɪd klin."

"If you ever meet a Malkieri," Noal said, "you tell him Jain Farstrider died clean."

"aɪ wɪl, dʒaɪn," mæt sɛd. "meɪ ðə laɪt hoʊl ju."

"I will, Jain," Mat said. "May the light hold you."

noʊl tɝn bæk tə feɪs ði æɛlfɪn ən mæt lɛf hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ bum əz ə naɪtfloʊɝ wɛn ɔf. ðən mæt hɝd noʊlz vɔɪs ɛkoʊ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ əz i skɹimd ə bæɾəlkɹi. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ɛni tʌŋ mæt hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd.

Noal turned back to face the Aelfinn and Mat left him. There was another boom as a nightflower went off. Then Mat heard Noal's voice echo down the corridor as he screamed a battlecry. It was not in any tongue Mat had ever heard.

hi ən tɑm ɛntɝɾ ənʌðɝ tʃeɪmbɝ. tɑm wɑz wipɪŋ, bʌt mæt hɛld ɪz tɪɹz. noʊl wəd daɪ wɪð ɑnɝ. wʌns, mæt wʊɾə θɔt ðət kaɪndə θɪŋkɪŋ fulɪʃ - wʌt ɡʊd wɑz ɑnɝ ɪf jə wɝ dɛd? bʌɾ i hæd tu mɛni mɛmɹiz ə soʊlʒɝz, hæd spɛn tu mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð mɛn u fɔɾ ən blɛd fəɹ ðəɾ ɑnɝ, tə dɪskɹɛɾət sətʃ noʊʃənz naʊ.

He and Thom entered another chamber. Thom was weeping, but Mat held his tears. Noal would die with honor. Once, Mat would have thought that kind of thinking foolish - what good was honor if you were dead? But he had too many memories of soldiers, had spent too much time with men who fought and bled for that honor, to discredit such notions now.

hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪ ən spʌn, mɔɪɹeɪnz weɪɾ ɔlmoʊst ənbælənsɪŋ hɪm. hi pɪkt ə dɝɛkʃən ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf pɔɪntɪŋ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm. hi tʃɑɹdʒ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, tɑm fɑloʊɪŋ.

He closed his eye and spun, Moiraine's weight almost unbalancing him. He picked a direction and found himself pointing back the way they had come. He charged down the corridor, Thom following.

wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði ɛn ə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ɪt dɪd nɑɾ oʊpən ɪndə ðə ɹum wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd lɛf noʊl.

When they reached the end of the corridor, it did not open into the room where they had left Noal.

ðɪs ɹum wɑz ɹaʊn ən wɑz fɪld wɪð jɛloʊ kɑləmz, meɪɾ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ɪnɔɹməs vaɪnz twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊnd wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð ən oʊpən sɪləndɝ ə speɪs ət ðə sɛntɝ. kɔɪld læmp stænz hɛld ɡlɑbz ʌv waɪt ðət ɡeɪv ðə ɹum ə sɑf laɪt, ən ðə flɔɹ wɑz taɪld ɪn ðə pæɾɝn ʌv waɪɾ ən jɛloʊ stʃɹɪps, spaɪɹəlɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ. ɪt smɛl pʌnʒəntli ʌv dʒɹaɪ sneɪkɛskɪn.

This room was round and was filled with yellow columns, made in the shape of enormous vines twisting around one another with an open cylinder of space at the center. Coiled lamp stands held globes of white that gave the room a soft light, and the floor was tiled in the pattern of white and yellow strips, spiraling out from the center. It smelled pungently of dry snakeskin.

meɪtʃɹim kɔθən, jəɹ noʊ hɪɹoʊ, hi θɔt, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðət mæn jə lɛf bɪhaɪnd, hiz ðə hɪɹoʊ. laɪɾ ɪlumin ju, noʊl.

Matrim Cauthon, you're no hero, he thought, glancing over his shoulder. That man you left behind, he's the hero. Light illumine you, Noal.

"naʊ wʌt?" θɔɹn æskt. hi sim tə hæv ɹəkʌvɝd səm ə hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ, soʊ mæt hændəd bæk mɔɪɹeɪn ən tʊk ɪz spɪɹ. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli tu dɔɹweɪz ɪn ðɪs ɹum, ðə wʌn bɪhaɪn ən wʌn dɝɛkli əkɹɔs ðə tʃeɪmbɝ. bʌt mæt spʌn wɪð ɪz aɪ kloʊzd ɛniweɪ. ðə lʌk pɔɪntəɾ əm tə ðə dɔɹweɪ ɑpəzət ðə wʌn ðeɪ hæɾ ɛntɝd.

"Now what?" Thorn asked. He seemed to have recovered some of his strength, so Mat handed back Moiraine and took his spear. There were only two doorways in this room, the one behind and one directly across the chamber. But Mat spun with his eye closed anyway. The luck pointed them to the doorway opposite the one they had entered.

ðeɪ tʊk ɪt. ðə wɪndoʊz ɪn ðɪs hɔlweɪ lʊkt aʊɾ ət ðə dʒʌŋɡəl, ən ðeɪ wɝ naʊ daʊn ɪn ðə θɪk ʌv ɪt. mæt əkeɪʒənəli spɑɾəd ðoʊz θɹi spaɪɹz. ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn moʊməns əɡoʊ, ðə pleɪs wɛɹ noʊl blɛd.

They took it. The windows in this hallway looked out at the jungle, and they were now down in the thick of it. Mat occasionally spotted those three spires. The place where they had been moments ago, the place where Noal bled.

"ðɪs ɪz wɛɹ jə ɡɑt jəɹ ænsɝz, ɪzən ɪt?" θɔɹn æskt.

"This is where you got your answers, isn't it?" Thorn asked.

mæt nɑɾəd.

Mat nodded.

"ju θɪŋk aɪ kəd ɡɛt səm ə ðoʊz maɪsɛlf?" tɑm æskt. "θɹi kwɛstʃənz. ɛni ænsɝz jə laɪk. . . ."

"You think I could get some of those myself?" Thom asked. "Three questions. Any answers you like. . . ."

"ju doʊnt wɑn ðɛm," mæt sɛd, tʌɡɪŋ daʊn ðə bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt. "tʃɹʌs mi, jə doʊnt. ðeɪ ɑɹən ænsɝz. ðəɹ θɹɛts. pɹɑməsəz. wi - "

"You don't want them," Mat said, tugging down the brim of his hat. "Trust me, you don't. They aren't answers. They're threats. Promises. We - "

tɑm stɑp bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪn θɔɹnz ɑɹmz, mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə stɝ. ʃi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɑft ɡɹoʊn, aɪz stɪl kloʊzd. bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt meɪd mæt fɹiz.

Thom stopped beside him. In Thorn's arms, Moiraine was beginning to stir. She let out a soft groan, eyes still closed. But that was not what made Mat freeze.

hi kəd si ənʌðɝ sɝkjəlɝ jɛloʊ ɹum ʌp əhɛd. sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðət ɹum wɑz ə ɹɛdstoʊn dɔɹweɪ. əɹ wʌt wɑz lɛft ʌv ɪt.

He could see another circular yellow room up ahead. Sitting in the middle of that room was a redstone doorway. Or what was left of it.

mæt kɝst, ɹʌnɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ðə flɔɹ wɑz stʃɹun wɪð tʃʌŋks ə ɹɛd ɹɑk ɹʌbəl. mæt ɡɹoʊnd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ ən teɪkɪŋ ə fju ʌv ðə tʃʌŋks, hoʊldɪŋ əm ʌp. ðə dɔɹweɪ hæd bɪn ʃæɾɝd baɪ sʌmθɪŋ, ə bloʊ ʌv ɑsəm fɔɹs.

Mat cursed, running forward. The floor was strewn with chunks of red rock rubble. Mat groaned, dropping his spear and taking a few of the chunks, holding them up. The doorway had been shattered by something, a blow of awesome force.

nɪɹ ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə ɹum, tɑm sæŋk daʊn, hoʊldɪŋ ðə stɝɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn. hi lʊkt ɪɡzɔstəd. niðɝ ə ðɛm hæɾ ə pæk ɛnimɔɹ; mæt hæd ɡɪvən ɪz tə noʊl, ən tɑm hæd lɛft ɪz bɪhaɪnd. ən ðɪs ɹum wɑz ə dɛɾ ɛnd, wɪð noʊ ʌðɝ dɔɹweɪz.

Near the entrance to the room, Thom sank down, holding the stirring Moiraine. He looked exhausted. Neither of them had a pack anymore; Mat had given his to Noal, and Thom had left his behind. And this room was a dead end, with no other doorways.

"bɝn ðɪs pleɪs!" mæt ʃaʊɾəd, ɹɪpɪŋ ɔf ɪz hæt, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ɪndə ði ɪkspænsɪv, ɛnləs dɑɹknəs əbʌv. "bɝn jə ɔl, sneɪks ən fɑksəz! dɑɹk wʌn teɪk ðə lɑɾ ə ju. juv maɪ aɪ, juv noʊl. ðæts ɪnʌf ʌv ə pɹaɪs fəɹ ju! ðæts tu mʌtʃ ʌv ə pɹaɪs! ɪzən ðə laɪf ə dʒaɪn blʌɾi fɑɹ-stʃɹaɪɾɝ ɪnʌf tə əpiz ju, jə mɑnstɝz!"

"Burn this place!" Mat shouted, ripping off his hat, staring up into the expansive, endless darkness above. "Burn you all, snakes and foxes! Dark One take the lot of you. You have my eye, you have Noal. That's enough of a price for you! That's too much of a price! Isn't the life of Jain bloody Far-strider enough to appease you, you monsters!"

hɪz wɝdz ɹæŋ ən vænɪʃt, wɪð noʊ ɹɪplaɪ. ði oʊld ɡlimən skwizd ɪz aɪz ʃʌt, hoʊldɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn. hi lʊk biɾən, ɡɹaʊn daʊn tə nʌθɪŋ. hɪz hænz wɝ ɹɛɾ ən blɪstɝd fɹəm pʊlɪŋ əɹ fɹi, hɪz koʊt slivz bɝnd.

His words rang and vanished, with no reply. The old gleeman squeezed his eyes shut, holding Moiraine. He looked beaten, ground down to nothing. His hands were red and blistered from pulling her free, his coat sleeves burned.

mæt lʊkt əbaʊt, dɛspɹɪt. hi tʃɹaɪd spɪnɪŋ əbaʊt wɪð aɪ kloʊz pɔɪntɪŋ. wən i oʊpən ɪz aɪ, hi wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum. ðə bɹoʊkən dɔɹweɪ.

Mat looked about, desperate. He tried spinning about with eye closed pointing. When he opened his eye, he was pointing at the center of the room. The broken doorway.

ɪt wɑz ðən ðəɾ i fɛl hoʊp stɑɹt tə daɪ ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm.

It was then that he felt hope start to die inside of him.

"ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd tʃɹaɪ, læd," θɔɹn sɛd. "wi dɪd wɛl. bɛɾɝ ðən wi ʃəɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd."

"It was a good try, lad," Thorn said. "We did well. Better than we should have expected."

"aɪ woʊnt ɡɪv ʌp," mæt sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪfaɪ ðə kɹʌʃɪŋ sɛns ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. "wil . . . wɪl ɹitʃɹeɪs əɹ stɛps, faɪn ə weɪ bæk tə ðə pleɪs bɪtwin ði æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn. ðə bɑɹɡən sɛd ðeɪ hæd tə liv ðət pɔɹɾəl oʊpən. wɪl teɪk ɪɾ ən ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ, θɔɹn. əl bi bɝn ɪf aɪm gɑnə daɪ ɪn hɪɹ. jə stɪl oʊ mi ə kʌpəl ə mʌɡz."

"I won't give up," Mat said, trying to defy the crushing sense inside of him. "We'll . . . we'll retrace our steps, find a way back to the place between the Aelfinn and Eelfinn. The bargain said they had to leave that portal open. We'll take it and get out of here, Thorn. I'll be burned if I'm going to die in here. You still owe me a couple of mugs."

θɔɹn oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən smaɪld, bʌt dɪd nɑt stæn ʌp. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðoʊz dʒɹupɪŋ mʌstæʃɪz wæɡɪŋ, ən lʊk daʊn ət mɔɪɹeɪn.

Thorn opened his eyes and smiled, but did not stand up. He shook his head, those drooping mustaches wagging, and looked down at Moiraine.

hɝ aɪz flʌɾɝd oʊpən. "θɔɹn," ʃi wɪspɝd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ hɝd jəɹ vɔɪs."

Her eyes fluttered open. "Thorn," she whispered, smiling. "I thought I heard your voice."

laɪt, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs tʊk mæt bæk. tə ʌðɝ taɪmz. eɪdʒəz əɡoʊ.

Light, but her voice took Mat back. To other times. Ages ago.

ʃi ɡlænst ət hɪm. "æn mæt. dɪɹ meɪtʃɹim. aɪ nu jə wəd kʌm fəɹ mi. boʊθ ə ju. aɪ wɪʃ jə hædnt, bʌɾ aɪ nu jə wʊd. . . ."

She glanced at him. "And Mat. Dear Matrim. I knew you would come for me. Both of you. I wish you hadn't, but I knew you would. . . ."

"ɹɛst, mɔɪɹeɪn," θɔɹn sɛd sɔfli. "wil bi aʊɾ ə hɪɹ ɪn tu stʃɹəmz ʌv ə hɑɹp."

"Rest, Moiraine," Thorn said softly. "We'll be out of here in two strums of a harp."

mæt lʊkt ət hɝ, laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ, hɛlpləs. "bɝn mi. aɪm nɑt gɑnə lɛɾ ɪɾ ɛn laɪk ðɪs!"

Mat looked at her, lying there, helpless. "Burn me. I'm not going to let it end like this!"

"ðeɪɹ kʌmɪŋ, læd," θɔɹn sɛd. "aɪ kən hɪɹ ðɛm."

"They're coming, lad," Thorn said. "I can hear them."

mæt tɝn tə lʊk θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ. hi kəd si wʌt θɔɹn hæd hɝd. ði æɛlfɪn kɹɛp θɹu ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, sɪnwəs ən dɛdli. ðeɪ smaɪld, ən i kəd si fæŋɡlaɪk ɪnsaɪzɝz ət ðə fɔɹfɹʌn ə ðoʊz smaɪlz. ðeɪ cʊɾə bɪn hjumən, seɪv fəɹ ðoʊz fæŋz. ən ðoʊz aɪz. ðoʊz ənnætʃɹəl, slɪɾɪd aɪz. ðeɪ muv slikli. tɛɹəbəl, iɡɝ.

Mat turned to look through the opening. He could see what Thorn had heard. The Aelfinn crept through the corridor, sinuous and deadly. They smiled, and he could see fanglike incisors at the forefront of those smiles. They could have been human, save for those fangs. And those eyes. Those unnatural, slitted eyes. They moved sleekly. Terrible, eager.

"noʊ," mæt wɪspɝd. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ." θɪŋk, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. mæt, jə ful. ðəɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ aʊt. haʊ dɪd jə ɪskeɪp ðə læs taɪm? noʊl hæɾ æskt. ðət wɑz noʊ hɛlp.

"No," Mat whispered. "There has to be a way." Think, he told himself. Mat, you fool. There has to be a way out. How did you escape the last time? Noal had asked. That was no help.

θɔɹn, lʊkɪŋ dɛspɹɪt, ənhʊkt ɪz hɑɹp fɹəm ɪz bæk. hi bɪɡæn tə pleɪ ɪt. mæt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə tun, "swit wɪspɝz ə təmɑɹoʊ." ə mɔɹnfəl saʊnd, pleɪd fəɹ ðə fɔlən dɛd. ɪt wɑz bjuɾəfəl.

Thorn, looking desperate, unhooked his harp from his back. He began to play it. Mat recognized the tune, "Sweet Whispers of Tomorrow." A mournful sound, played for the fallen dead. It was beautiful.

ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, ðə mjuzɪk dɪd sim tə suð ði æɛlfɪn. ðeɪ sloʊd, ðə wʌnz ət ðə fɹʌn bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə sweɪ tə ðə biɾ ə ðə mɛləɾi əz ðeɪ wɔkt. ðeɪ nu. θɔɹn pleɪd fəɹ ɪz oʊn fjunɝəl.

Remarkably, the music did seem to soothe the Aelfinn. They slowed, the ones at the front beginning to sway to the beat of the melody as they walked. They knew. Thorn played for his own funeral.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ aɪ ɡɑɾ aʊt læs taɪm," mæt wɪspɝd. "aɪ wɑz ʌnkɑnʃəs. aɪ woʊk ʌp biɪŋ hæŋd. ɹænd kʌt mi daʊn."

"I don't know how I got out last time," Mat whispered. "I was unconscious. I woke up being hanged. Rand cut me down."

hi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɪz skɑɹ. hɪz ɝɪdʒənəl æɛlfɪn ænsɝz ɹɪvil nʌθɪŋ. hi nu əbaʊt ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, hi nu əbaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp hæf ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝld. hi nu əbaʊt ɹɪɾiən. ɪɾ ɔl meɪd sɛns. noʊ hoʊlz. noʊ kwɛstʃənz.

He raised a hand to his scar. His original Aelfinn answers revealed nothing. He knew about the Daughter of the Nine Moons, he knew about giving up half the light of the world. He knew about Rhuidean. It all made sense. No holes. No questions.

ɪksɛpt. . . .

Except. . . .

wʌd ði ɛlfɪn ɡɪv ju?

What did the Eelfinn give you?

"ɪf aɪ hæd maɪ weɪ," mæt wɪspɝd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ æɛlfɪn, "aɪ wəd wɑn ðoʊz hoʊlz fɪld."

"If I had my way," Mat whispered, staring at the oncoming Aelfinn, "I would want those holes filled."

ði æɛlfɪn slaɪðɝd fɔɹwɝd, wɛɹɪŋ ðoʊz klɔθs ə jɛloʊ ɹæpɪŋ ðɛɹ bɑɾiz. θɔɹnz mjuzɪk spʌn ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɛkoʊɪŋ. ðə kɹitʃɝz əpɹoʊtʃt wɪð stɛɾi, sloʊ stɛps. ðeɪ nu ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ pɹeɪ naʊ.

The Aelfinn slithered forward, wearing those cloths of yellow wrapping their bodies. Thorn's music spun in the air, echoing. The creatures approached with steady, slow steps. They knew they had their prey now.

ðə tu æɛlfɪn ət ðə fɹʌn kæɹid sɔɹdz ʌv ɡlimɪŋ bɹɑnz, dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɹɛd. pʊɹ noʊl.

The two Aelfinn at the front carried swords of gleaming bronze, dripping red. Poor Noal.

tɑm bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ. "oʊ, haʊ lɔŋ wɝ ðə deɪz ʌv ə mæn. wən i stʃɹoʊɾ əpɑn ə bɹoʊkən lænd."

Thom began to sing. "Oh, how long were the days of a man. When he strode upon a broken land."

mæt lɪsənd, mɛmɹiz blɑsəmɪŋ ɪn ɪz maɪnd. θɔɹnz vɔɪs kæɹiɾ ɪm tə deɪz lɔŋ əɡoʊ. deɪz ɪn ɪz oʊn mɛmɹiz, deɪz ə ðə mɛmɹiz ʌv ʌðɝz. deɪz wən i hæd daɪd, deɪz wən i hæd lɪvd, deɪz wən i hæd fɔɾ ən wən i hæd wʌn.

Mat listened, memories blossoming in his mind. Thorn's voice carried him to days long ago. Days in his own memories, days of the memories of others. Days when he had died, days when he had lived, days when he had fought and when he had won.

"aɪ wɑn ðoʊz hoʊlz fɪld . . ." mæt wɪspɝd tə hɪmsɛlf. "ðæts wʌɾ aɪ sɛd. ði ɛlfɪn əblaɪdʒd, ɡɪvɪŋ mi mɛmɹiz ðət wɝ nɑt maɪ oʊn."

"I want those holes filled . . ." Mat whispered to himself. "That's what I said. The Eelfinn obliged, giving me memories that were not my own."

mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz hæd kloʊzd əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi smaɪld əz ʃi lɪsən tə θɔɹnz mjuzɪk. mæt hæd θɔt tɑm wɑz pleɪɪŋ fəɹ ði æɛlfɪn, bʌt naʊ hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i wɑz pleɪɪŋ fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn. ə læst, mɛlənkɑli sɔŋ fəɹ ə feɪld ɹɛskju.

Moiraine's eyes had closed again, but she smiled as she listened to Thorn's music. Mat had thought Thom was playing for the Aelfinn, but now he wondered if he was playing for Moiraine. A last, melancholy song for a failed rescue.

"hi seɪld əz fɑɹ əz ə mæn kəd stɪɹ," tɑm sæŋ, vɔɪs sɑnɝəs, bjuɾəfəl. "æn i nɛvɝ wɪʃt tə luz ɪz fɪɹ."

"He sailed as far as a man could steer," Thom sang, voice sonorous, beautiful. "And he never wished to lose his fear."

"aɪ wɑn ðoʊz hoʊlz fɪld," mæt ɹɪpiɾɪd, "soʊ ðeɪ ɡeɪv mi mɛmɹiz. ðət wɑz maɪ fɝs bun."

"I want those holes filled," Mat repeated, "so they gave me memories. That was my first boon."

"fɔɹ ðə fɪɹ ə mæn ɪz ə θɪŋ əntoʊld. ɪt kips ɪm seɪf, ən ɪt pɹuvz ɪm boʊld!"

"For the fear of man is a thing untold. It keeps him safe, and it proves him bold!"

"aɪ æsk sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, nɑt noʊɪŋ ɪt," mæt sɛd. "aɪ sɛɾ aɪ wɑntəd tə bi fɹi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə paʊɝ. ðeɪ ɡeɪv mi ðə mədæljən fəɹ ðæt. ənʌðɝ ɡɪft."

"I asked something else, not knowing it," Mat said. "I said I wanted to be free of Aes Sedai and the Power. They gave me the medallion for that. Another gift."

"doʊn lɛt fɪɹ meɪk jə sis tə stʃɹaɪv, fəɹ ðət fɪɹ ɪt pɹuvz jə ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv!"

"Don't let fear make you cease to strive, for that fear it proves you remain alive!"

"ænd . . . ən aɪ æsk fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ. aɪ sɛɾ aɪ wɑntəd tə bi əweɪ fɹəm əm ən bæk tə ɹɪɾiən. ði ɛlfɪn ɡeɪv mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ æsk fɔɹ. ðə mɛmɹiz tə fɪl maɪ hoʊlz. ðə mədæljən tə kip mi fɹi fɹəm ðə paʊɝ. . . ."

"And . . . and I asked for one more thing. I said I wanted to be away from them and back to Rhuidean. The Eelfinn gave me everything I asked for. The memories to fill my holes. The medallion to keep me free from the Power. . . ."

ən wʌt? ðeɪ sɛn ɪm bæk tə ɹɪɾiən tə hæŋ. bʌt hæŋɪŋ wɑz ə pɹaɪs, nɑɾ ən ænsɝ tə hɪz dɪmænz.

And what? They sent him back to Rhuidean to hang. But hanging was a price, not an answer to his demands.

"aɪ wɪl wɔk ðɪs bɹoʊkən ɹoʊd," θɔɹn sæŋ, vɔɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ, "æn əl kæɹi ə hɛvi loʊd!"

"I will walk this broken road," Thorn sang, voice growing louder, "and I will carry a heavy load!"

"ðeɪ dɪd ɡɪmi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls," mæt wɪspɝd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn ɪz hænz əz ði æɛlfɪn bɪɡæn tə hɪs mɔɹ laʊdli.

"They did give me something else," Mat whispered, looking down at the ashandarei in his hands as the Aelfinn began to hiss more loudly.

ðʌs ɪz əɹ tʃɹiɾi ɹɪɾən; ðʌs ɪz əɡɹimən meɪd.

Thus is our treaty written; thus is agreement made.

ɪt wɑz kɑɹvd ɑn ðə wɛpən. ðə bleɪd hæd tu ɹeɪvənz, ðə ʃæft ɪnskɹaɪbd wɪð wɝdz ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ.

It was carved on the weapon. The blade had two ravens, the shaft inscribed with words in the Old Tongue.

θɔɾ ɪz ði æɹoʊ ʌv taɪm; mɛmɹi nɛvɝ feɪdz.

Thought is the arrow of time; memory never fades.

waɪ hæd ðeɪ ɡɪvən tə hɪm? hi hæd nɛvɝ kwɛstʃən ɪt. bʌɾ i hæd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ ə wɛpən.

Why had they given to him? He had never questioned it. But he had not asked for a weapon.

wʌt wɑz æskt ɪz ɡɪvən. ðə pɹaɪs ɪz peɪd.

What was asked is given. The price is paid.

noʊ, aɪ dɪdn æsk fəɹ ə wɛpən. aɪ æsk fəɹ ə weɪ aʊt.

No, I didn't ask for a weapon. I asked for a way out.

ən ðeɪ ɡeɪv mi ðɪs.

And they gave me this.

"soʊ kʌm ət mi wɪð jəɹ ɑfəl laɪz," θɔɹn bɛloʊd ðə faɪnəl laɪn ə ðə sɔŋ. "ɪm ə mæn ə tʃɹuθ, ən əl mit jəɹ aɪz!"

"So come at me with your awful lies," Thorn bellowed the final line of the song. "I'm a man of truth, and I'll meet your eyes!"

mæt spʌn ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ən θɹʌst ɪɾ ɪndə ðə wɔl. ðə pɔɪn sæŋk ɪndə ðə nɑt-stoʊn. laɪt spɹeɪɾ aʊɾ ɝaʊn ɪt, spɪlɪŋ fɹi laɪk blʌd ɡʌʃɪŋ fɹəm ə splɪt veɪn. mæt skɹimd, ɹæmɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn fɑɹðɝ.

Mat spun the ashandarei and thrust it into the wall. The point sank into the not-stone. Light sprayed out around it, spilling free like blood gushing from a split vein. Mat screamed, ramming it in farther.

paʊɝfəl weɪvz ə laɪɾ ɪɹʌptəd fɹəm ðə wɔl.

Powerful waves of light erupted from the wall.

hi dʒɹu ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ daʊn əɾ ən æŋɡəl, meɪkɪŋ ə slɪt. hi pʊl ðə wɛpən ʌp ði ʌðɝ saɪd, kʌɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɪnvɝs tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl ə laɪt. ðə laɪt sim tə θɹəm əz ɪt wɑʃt əkɹɔs hɪm. ði æɛlfɪn hæd ɹitʃt ðə dɔɹweɪ baɪ θɔɹn, bʌt ðeɪ hɪst, ʃaɪɪŋ bæk fɹəm ðə paʊɝfəl ɹeɪdʒjəns.

He drew the ashandarei down at an angle, making a slit. He pulled the weapon up the other side, cutting out a large inverse triangle of light. The light seemed to thrum as it washed across him. The Aelfinn had reached the doorway by Thorn, but they hissed, shying back from the powerful radiance.

mæt fɪnɪʃt baɪ dʒɹɔɪŋ ə weɪvi laɪn daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl. hi kəd bɛɹli si, ðə laɪt wɑz soʊ bɹaɪt. ðə sɛkʃən ə ðə wɔl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm fɛl əweɪ, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə ɡloʊɪŋ waɪt pæsədʒ ðət sim tə bi kʌɾ aʊɾ ə stil.

Mat finished by drawing a wavy line down the middle of the triangle. He could barely see, the light was so bright. The section of the wall in front of him fell away, revealing a glowing white passage that seemed to be cut out of steel.

"wɛl əl . . ." θɔɹn wɪspɝd, stændɪŋ ʌp.

"Well I'll . . ." Thorn whispered, standing up.

ði æɛlfɪn skɹimd wɪð haɪ-pɪtʃt æŋɡɝ. ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə ɹum, ɑɹmz ɹeɪz tə ʃil ðɛɹ aɪz, wɪkəd sɔɹdz ɡɹɪpt ɪn əpoʊzɪŋ hænz.

The Aelfinn screamed with high-pitched anger. They entered the room, arms raised to shield their eyes, wicked swords gripped in opposing hands.

"ɡɛɾ əɹ aʊt!" mæt bɛloʊd, spɪnɪŋ tə feɪs ðə kɹitʃɝz. hi lɪftəd ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ, juzɪŋ ðə bʌɾ ɛn tə smæʃ ðə feɪs ə ðə fɝst æɛlfɪn. "ɡoʊ!"

"Get her out!" Mat bellowed, spinning to face the creatures. He lifted the ashandarei, using the butt end to smash the face of the first Aelfinn. "Go!"

θɔɹn ɡɹæb mɔɪɹeɪn, ðən spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns ət mæt.

Thorn grabbed Moiraine, then spared a glance at Mat.

"ɡoʊ!" mæt ɹɪpiɾɪd, smæʃɪŋ ði ɑɹm ʌv ənʌðɝ æɛlfɪn.

"Go!" Mat repeated, smashing the arm of another Aelfinn.

tɑm lɛpt ɪndə ðə dɔɹweɪ ən vænɪʃt. mæt smaɪld, spɪnɪŋ əmʌŋ ði æɛlfɪn wɪð ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, leɪɪŋ ɪndə lɛɡz, ɑɹmz, hɛdz. ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɾ ə ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ sim deɪz baɪ ðə laɪt, fɹɛnzid tə ɡɛt tə hɪm. əz i tʃɹɪp ðə fɝs fju, ði ʌðɝz stʌmbəld. ðə kɹitʃɝz bɪkeɪm ə skwɝmɪŋ mæs ə sɪnwəs ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz, hɪsɪŋ ən spɪɾɪŋ ɪn æŋɡɝ, sɛvɹəl ə ðoʊz ɪn bæk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɹɔl oʊvɝ ðə paɪl tə ɹitʃ hɪm.

Thom leaped into the doorway and vanished. Mat smiled, spinning among the Aelfinn with his ashandarei, laying into legs, arms, heads. There were a lot of them, but they seemed dazed by the light, frenzied to get to him. As he tripped the first few, the others stumbled. The creatures became a squirming mass of sinuous arms and legs, hissing and spitting in anger, several of those in back trying to crawl over the pile to reach him.

mæt stɛp bæk ən tɪpt ɪz hæt tə ðə kɹitʃɝz. "lʊks laɪk ðə ɡeɪm kən bi wʌn æftɝ ɔl,"

Mat stepped back and tipped his hat to the creatures. "Looks like the game can be won after all,"

hi sɛd. "tɛl ðə fɑksəz aɪm maɪɾi plizd wɪð ðɪs ki ðeɪ ɡeɪv mi. ɔlsoʊ, jə kən ɔl ɡoʊ ɹɑɾ ɪn ə fleɪmɪŋ pɪɾ ə faɪɝ ən æʃəz, jə ənwɑʃt lʌmps ɑn ə pɪɡz bæksaɪd. hæv ə ɡɹæn blʌɾi deɪ."

he said. "Tell the foxes I'm mighty pleased with this key they gave me. Also, you can all go rot in a flaming pit of fire and ashes, you unwashed lumps on a pig's backside. Have a grand bloody day."

hi hɛld ɪz hæɾ ən lɛp θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ.

He held his hat and leaped through the opening.

ɔl flæʃt waɪt.

All flashed white.


tʃæptɝ fɪftisɪks


CHAPTER 56

sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ


Something Wrong

ə sɑf nɑk keɪm ət ðə poʊst aʊtsaɪɾ ɛɡwinz tɛnt. "kʌm," ʃi sɛd, ʃʌflɪŋ θɹu ðə peɪpɝz ɑn əɹ dɛsk. ɡɔɪn slɪpt ɪn. hid ɡɪvən ʌp ɪz faɪn kloʊðɪŋ, tʃuzɪŋ tʃɹaʊzɝz ə bɹaʊn ən ə slaɪtli laɪɾɝ ʃɝt. eɪ wɔɹɾɝz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk hʌŋ ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, meɪkɪŋ ɪm blɛn ɪndə hɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz. ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə ɹiɡəl dʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹin ən blu.

A soft knock came at the post outside Egwene's tent. "Come," she said, shuffling through the papers on her desk. Gawyn slipped in. He'd given up his fine clothing, choosing trousers of brown and a slightly lighter shirt. A Warders color-shifting cloak hung around his shoulders, making him blend into his surroundings. Egwene herself was wearing a regal dress of green and blue.

hɪz kloʊk ɹʌsəld əz i tʊk ə sit bɪsaɪɾ əɹ dɛsk. "ɪleɪnz ɑɹmi ɪz kɹɔsɪŋ. ʃi sɛnt wɝd ðət ʃiz ɑn əɹ weɪ tə kʌm vɪzəɾ əɹ kæmp."

His cloak rustled as he took a seat beside her desk. "Elayne's army is crossing. She sent word that she's on her way to come visit our camp."

"ɛksələnt," ɛɡwin sɛd. ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd, bʌɾ i wɑz tʃɹʌbəld. sətʃ ə jusfəl θɪŋ, ðət bɔl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz kɑz baɪ ðə bɑnd. ɪf ʃid noʊn ɝliɝ ðə dɛpθ ə hɪz dɪvoʊʃən tə hɝ, ʃiɾ əv bɑndəɾ ɪm wiks əɡoʊ. "wʌt?" ɛɡwin æskt, sɛɾɪŋ əsaɪɾ əɹ peɪpɝz.

"Excellent," Egwene said. Gawyn nodded, but he was troubled. Such a useful thing, that ball of emotions caused by the bond. If she'd known earlier the depth of his devotion to her, she'd have bonded him weeks ago. "What?" Egwene asked, setting aside her papers.

"eɪbɑɹə," hi sɛd. "hi hæzən əɡɹid tə mit wɪð ju."

"Aybara," he said. "He hasn't agreed to meet with you."

"ɪleɪn sɛɾ i maɪt bi dɪfəkəlt."

"Elayne said he might be difficult."

"aɪ θɪŋk hiz gɑnə teɪk ælθɹz saɪd," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ju kən si ɪɾ ɪn ðə weɪ hi sɛɾ ʌp kæmp, əpɑɹt fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. hi sɛn mɛsənʒɝz ɪmiɾiətli tə ði il ən tə ðə tɛɹənz. hiz ɡɑɾ ə ɡʊɾ ɑɹmi, ɛɡwin. ə hjudʒ wʌn. wɪð waɪtkloʊks ɪn ɪt."

"I think he's going to take al'Thor's side," Gawyn said. "You can see it in the way he set up camp, apart from everyone else. He sent messengers immediately to the Aiel and to the Tairens. He's got a good army, Egwene. A huge one. With Whitecloaks in it."

"ðæt dʌzn saʊn laɪkli tə meɪk ɪm saɪd wɪð ɹænd," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"That doesn't sound likely to make him side with Rand," Egwene said.

"dʌzn sim laɪk ɪt meɪks ɪm laɪkli tə saɪd wɪð əs iðɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ɛɡwin . . . ɡɑləd lidz ðə waɪtkloʊks."

"Doesn't seem like it makes him likely to side with us either," Gawyn said. "Egwene . . . Galad leads the Whitecloaks."

"jɔɹ bɹʌðɝ?"

"Your brother?"

"jɛs." ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðɪs mɛni ɑɹmiz, ðɪs mɛni lɔɪəltiz, ɔl ɹʌbɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. eɪbɑɹə ən ɪz fɔɹs kəd bi ə spɑɹk ðət sɛnz əs ɔl ʌp laɪk ə faɪɝwɝk."

"Yes." Gawyn shook his head. "This many armies, this many loyalties, all rubbing against one another. Aybara and his force could be a spark that sends us all up like a firework."

"ɪt wɪl bi bɛɾɝ wən ɪleɪn sɛɾəlz ɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"It will be better when Elayne settles in," Egwene said.

"ɛɡwin, wʌɾ ɪf ælθɹ ɪzən kʌmɪŋ? wʌɾ ɪf i dɪd ðɪs tə dɪstʃɹækt ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ ɛls hiz duɪŋ?"

"Egwene, what if al'Thor isn't coming? What if he did this to distract everyone from whatever else he's doing?"

"waɪ wəɾ i də ðæt?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "hiz ɔlɹɛɾi pɹuvən ðəɾ i kən əvɔɪd biɪŋ faʊnd, ɪf i wɑns tə." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɡɔɪn, hi noʊz i ʃʊdn bɹeɪk ðoʊz silz. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm dʌz, ət list. pɝhæps ðæts waɪ hi toʊl mi - soʊ aɪ kəd ɡæðɝ ɹɪzɪstəns, soʊ aɪ kəd tɔk ɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt."

"Why would he do that?" Egwene said. "He's already proven that he can avoid being found, if he wants to." She shook her head. "Gawyn, he knows he shouldn't break those seals. A part of him does, at least. Perhaps that's why he told me - so I could gather resistance, so I could talk him out of it."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd. noʊ fɝðɝ kəmpleɪn əɹ ɑɹɡjəmənt. ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ haʊ hid tʃeɪnʒd. hi wɑz əz ɪntɛns əz ɛvɝ, jɛt lɛs əbɹeɪsɪv. ɛvɝ sɪns ðət naɪt wɪð ði əsæsənz, hi hæd stɑɹɾəd duɪŋ əz ʃi æskt. nɑɾ əz ə sɝvənt. əz ə pɑɹtnɝ dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə siɪŋ əɹ wɪl dʌn.

Gawyn nodded. No further complaint or argument. It was a wonder how he'd changed. He was as intense as ever, yet less abrasive. Ever since that night with the assassins, he had started doing as she asked. Not as a servant. As a partner dedicated to seeing her will done.

ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝfəl θɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, sɪns ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ sim dɪtɝmən tə oʊvɝtɝn ðɛɹ əɡɹimən tə lɛɾ əɹ teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ ə dilɪŋz wɪð ɹænd. ʃi lʊk daʊn əɾ əɹ stæk ə peɪpɝz, nɑɾ ə fju ʌv wɪtʃ wɝ lɛɾɝz ʌv "ædvaɪs" fɹəm sɪɾɝz.

It was a wonderful thing. It was also important, since the Hall of the Tower seemed determined to overturn their agreement to let her take charge of dealings with Rand. She looked down at her stack of papers, not a few of which were letters of "advice" from Sitters.

bʌt ðeɪ keɪm tə hɝ, ɹæðɝ ðən sɝkəmvɛntɪŋ hɝ. ðət wɑz ɡʊd, ən ʃi kʊdn ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm.

But they came to her, rather than circumventing her. That was good, and she couldn't ignore them.

ʃi hæd tə meɪk əm kəntɪnju tə bɪliv ðət wɝkɪŋ wɪð əɹ wɑz fəɹ ðə bɛst. ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ʃi kʊdn lɛɾ əm əsum ðət ʃid bi bloʊn oʊvɝ baɪ ə fju ɡʊd ʃaʊts.

She had to make them continue to believe that working with her was for the best. At the same time, she couldn't let them assume that she'd be blown over by a few good shouts.

sətʃ ə dɛləkət bæləns. "wɛl, lɛts ɡoʊ mit jəɹ sɪstɝ, ðɛn."

Such a delicate balance. "Well, let's go meet your sister, then."

ɡɔɪn ɹoʊz, muvɪŋ smuðli. ðə θɹi ɹɪŋz i wɔɹ ɑn ə tʃeɪn ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk ɹæɾəld əz i muvd; ʃiɾ əv tə æsk ɪm əɡɛn wɛɹ hid ɡɑɾən ðoʊz. hi hæd bɪn ɑdli kloʊsəməðd əbaʊt ðɛm. hi hɛld oʊpən ðə tɛn flæps fəɹ hɝ, ən ʃi stɛpt aʊt.

Gawyn rose, moving smoothly. The three rings he wore on a chain around his neck rattled as he moved; she'd have to ask him again where he'd gotten those. He had been oddly closemouthed about them. He held open the tent flaps for her, and she stepped out.

aʊtsaɪd, ðə leɪt-æftɝnun sʌn wɑz hɪɾən baɪ ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz. bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz wɝk bɪzəli ɑn ə pælɪsɑd. hɪz ɑɹmi hæd swɛl dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs fju wiks, ən ðeɪ dɑməneɪɾəd ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə waɪd, fɔɹəst-ɹɪmd ɡɹæslæn ðət hæd wʌns bɪn noʊn əz mɛɹɪlɝ. ðə ɹuənz ə ðə taʊɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs ðət hæd stʊd hɪɹ wɝ stʃɹun əkɹɔs ðə nɔɹðɝn saɪɾ ə ðə fild, mɔs-kʌvɝd, nɪɹli hɪɾən baɪ tʃoʊkɪvaɪn.

Outside, the late-afternoon sun was hidden by gray clouds. Bryne's soldiers worked busily on a palisade. His army had swelled during the last few weeks, and they dominated the eastern side of the wide, forest-rimmed grassland that had once been known as Merrilor. The ruins of the tower fortress that had stood here were strewn across the northern side of the field, moss-covered, nearly hidden by chokevine.

ɛɡwinz tɛnt wɑz ɑn ə ɹaɪz, ən ʃi kəɾ oʊvɝlʊk ðə mɛni ɑɹmiz ɪnkæmp hɪɹ. "ɪz ðət wʌn nu?" ʃi æskt, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə smɔlɝ fɔɹs ðət hæd teɪkən ʌp ə pəzɪʃən dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə ɹuənz.

Egwene's tent was on a rise, and she could overlook the many armies encamped here. "Is that one new?" she asked, gesturing toward a smaller force that had taken up a position just below the ruins.

"ðeɪ keɪm ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "fɑɹmɝz, moʊsli. nɑt ɹɪli ə tʃɹu ɑɹmi; moʊs doʊn əv sɔɹdz. pɪtʃfɔɹks, wʊɾ æksiz, kɔɹɾɝstɑfs. aɪ əsum ælθɹ sɛn ðɛm. ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd wɑndɝɪŋ ɪn jɛstɝdeɪ."

"They came on their own," Gawyn said. "Farmers, mostly. Not really a true army; most don't have swords. Pitchforks, wood axes, quarterstaffs. I assume al'Thor sent them. They started wandering in yesterday."

"kjʊɹiəs," ɛɡwin sɛd. ðeɪ simd ə vɛɹid bʌntʃ, wɪð mɪsmætʃt tɛns ən lɪɾəl ʌndɝstændɪŋ ə haʊ tə sɛɾ ʌp ən ɑɹmi kæmp. bʌt ðəɹ dɪd sim tə bi səm faɪv əɹ tɛn θaʊzən ə ðɛm. "hæv səm skaʊts kip ən aɪ ɑn ðɛm."

"Curious," Egwene said. They seemed a varied bunch, with mismatched tents and little understanding of how to set up an army camp. But there did seem to be some five or ten thousand of them. "Have some scouts keep an eye on them."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd.

Gawyn nodded.

ɛɡwin tɝn ən noʊɾəd ə pɹəsɛʃən muvɪŋ θɹu sɛvɹəl ɡeɪtweɪz nɪɹbaɪ, sɛɾɪŋ ʌp kæmp.

Egwene turned and noted a procession moving through several gateways nearby, setting up camp.

ðə laɪən ʌv ændɝ flu haɪ əbʌv əm ən ðə soʊlʒɝz mɑɹtʃt ɪn ɔɹɾɝli ɹoʊz. ə pɹəsɛʃən ɪn ɹɛɾ ən waɪt hæd lɛft əm ən wɑz mɑɹtʃɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwinz kæmp, ðə bænɝ ə ðə kwin flaɪɪŋ əbʌv ðɛm.

The Lion of Andor flew high above them and the soldiers marched in orderly rows. A procession in red and white had left them and was marching toward Egwene's camp, the banner of the Queen flying above them.

ɡɔɪn əkʌmpəniɾ ɛɡwin əkɹɔs ðə jɛloʊd ɡɹæs tə miɾ ɪleɪn. ði ændɔɝən kwin hæd sɝɾənli teɪkən əɹ taɪm. oʊnli wʌn deɪ əntɪl ðə taɪm spɛsəfaɪd baɪ ɹænd. stɪl, ʃi hæd kʌm, əz hæɾ ʌðɝz. il hæɾ əkʌmpənid dɑɹlɪn fɹəm tiɹ, ən əɹ pɝsweɪʒən hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ kəntɪnʒənt ʌv ɪliɑnɝz, hu kæmpt ɑn ðə wɛstɝn saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹæs.

Gawyn accompanied Egwene across the yellowed grass to meet Elayne. The Andoran Queen had certainly taken her time. Only one day until the time specified by Rand. Still, she had come, as had others. Aiel had accompanied Darlin from Tear, and her persuasion had been enough to bring a large contingent of Illianers, who camped on the western side of the grass.

ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɝ ɪleɪnz naʊ, baɪ ɹɪpɔɹts, ən wɝ kʌmɪŋ θɹu wɪð ði ændɔɹənz ən ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə mɛn fɹəm ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd. ɛɡwin hæd sɛn ən ɔfɝ, ən ə wʊmən tə ɔfɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ, tə kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən ə mʊɹændi, bʌt ʃi wɑz ənsɝɾən ɪf i wəd kʌm. ivən wɪθaʊt hɪm, haʊɛvɝ, ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl nʌmbɝ ə ðə wɝlz neɪʃənz wɝ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd hɪɹ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns ðə flæɡz ʌv ɡildən ən min kəd bi sin əmʌŋ pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmiz. ʃi wəɾ əv tə kɑntæk ðɛɹ tu ɹulɝz ən si ɪf ʃi kəd sweɪ ðɛm tə hɝ weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ. bʌɾ ivən ɪf nɑt, ʃʊɹli wʌt ʃi hæd ɡæðɝd wəd bi ɪnʌf tə kənvɪns ɹænd tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz plænz. laɪt sɛn ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf. ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf i fɔɹst əɹ hænd.

The Cairhienin were Elayne's now, by reports, and were coming through with the Andorans and a large number of men from the Band of the Red Hand. Egwene had sent an offer, and a woman to offer Traveling, to King Roedran of Murandy, but she was uncertain if he would come. Even without him, however, a considerable number of the world's nations were represented here, particularly since the flags of Ghealdan and Mayene could be seen among Perrin's armies. She would have to contact their two rulers and see if she could sway them to her way of thinking. But even if not, surely what she had gathered would be enough to convince Rand to change his plans. Light send it was enough. She didn't want to think of what would happen if he forced her hand.

ʃi wɔk daʊn ðə pæθweɪ, nɑɾɪŋ bæk tə sɪstɝz u nɑɾəd ən æksɛptɪɾ u kɝtsid, soʊlʒɝz u səluɾəd ən sɝvəns u baʊd. ɹænd wəd -  "ɪt kæn bi," ɡɔɪn sɛd sʌɾənli, fɹizɪŋ ɪn pleɪs.

She walked down the pathway, nodding back to sisters who nodded and Accepted who curtsied, soldiers who saluted and servants who bowed. Rand would -  "It can't be," Gawyn said suddenly, freezing in place.

"ɡɔɪn?" ʃi sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ɑɹ jə - "

"Gawyn?" she said, frowning. "Are you - "

hi tʊk ɔf əɾ ə ɹʌn əkɹɔs ðə wid-stʃɹun hɪl. ɛɡwin lʊkt æftɝ ɪm wɪð dɪsæɾɪsfækʃən.

He took off at a run across the weed-strewn hill. Egwene looked after him with dissatisfaction.

hi stɪl hæɾ ən ɪmpʌlsɪv stʃɹik. waɪ wɑz i soʊ ʌpsɛt, sʌɾənli? ɪt wɑznt wɝi; ʃi kəd fil ðæt.

He still had an impulsive streak. Why was he so upset, suddenly? It wasn't worry; she could feel that.

ɪt wɑz kənfjuʒən. ʃi heɪsən æftɝ ɪm wɪð əz mʌtʃ spiɾ əz dɪkɔɹəm wəɾ əlaʊ. ɪleɪnz ɛnvɔɪ hæd stɑpt ɪn ðə dɛd ɡɹæs.

It was confusion. She hastened after him with as much speed as decorum would allow. Elayne's envoy had stopped in the dead grass.

ɡɔɪn wɑz ɑn ɪz niz ðɛɹ, bɪfɔɹ sʌmwʌn. ən oʊldɝ wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə smaɪlɪŋ ɪleɪn, hu stɪl sæɾ əɹ hɔɹs.

Gawyn was on his knees there, before someone. An older woman with red-gold hair, standing beside a smiling Elayne, who still sat her horse.

ɑ, ɛɡwin θɔt. hɝ spaɪz hæd dɪlɪvɝd wɝɾ ə ðɪs ɹumɝ dʒʌs læs naɪt, bʌt ʃid wɑntəd tə kənfɝm ɪt bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ tə ɡɔɪn.

Ah, Egwene thought. Her spies had delivered word of this rumor just last night, but she'd wanted to confirm it before speaking to Gawyn.

mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkən lɪvd.

Morgase Trakand lived.

ɛɡwin stʊd bæk, fəɹ naʊ. wʌns ʃi stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ɪleɪn wəɾ əv tə kɪs əɹ ɹɪŋ ən ði ɪntaɪɝ pɹəsɛʃən wəd baʊ; ðət wəd spɔɪl ɡɔɪnz moʊmənt. əz ʃi weɪɾəd, ðə klaʊdz əbʌv ɡɹu θɪnɝ.

Egwene stood back, for now. Once she stepped forward, Elayne would have to kiss her ring and the entire procession would bow; that would spoil Gawyn's moment. As she waited, the clouds above grew thinner.

sʌɾənli ðeɪ splɪt, ðə dɑɹk θʌndɝhɛdz pʊlɪŋ bæk. ðə skaɪ bɪkeɪm ən oʊpən fild ə blu, ə dip, pjʊɹ ɪkspæns. ɪleɪnz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən ʃi tɝn ɑn əɹ hɔɹs, lʊkɪŋ ət pɛɹɪnz sɛkʃən ə kæmp.

Suddenly they split, the dark thunderheads pulling back. The sky became an open field of blue, a deep, pure expanse. Elayne's eyes opened wide, and she turned on her horse, looking at Perrin's section of camp.

hiz kʌm, ðɛn, ɛɡwin θɔt. ən ðə kɑm ɪz hɪɹ. ðə bɹif moʊmən ə pis bɪfɔɹ ðə stɔɹm ðət dɪstʃɹɔɪz.

He's come, then, Egwene thought. And the calm is here. The brief moment of peace before the storm that destroys.

"ju ɡɪv ɪɾ ə tʃɹaɪ, əmɝɪn," ænʒɹəl sɛd, stændɪŋ wɪð ə smɔl ɡɹup ɪnsaɪɾ ə stæn ə tʃɹiz nɪɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə ðə blæk taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz.

"You give it a try, Emarin," Androl said, standing with a small group inside a stand of trees near the border of the Black Tower grounds.

ðə steɪtli noʊbəlmən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. wivz spɹæŋ ʌp ɝaʊn hɪm. hi wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbli skɪlfəl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɪz ʃɔɹt taɪm pɹæktəsɪŋ, ən ɛkspɝtli kɹæftɪd ðə wiv fəɹ ə ɡeɪtweɪ.

The stately nobleman concentrated, holding the One Power. Weaves sprang up around him. He was remarkably skillful, considering his short time practicing, and expertly crafted the weave for a gateway.

ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊpənɪŋ ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðə wiv ənɹævəld ən vænɪʃt. əmɝɪn tɝn tə ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm, swɛt stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn ɪz feɪs. "fɔɹmɪŋ ðoʊz wivz sim hɑɹɾɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ," hi sɛd.

Instead of opening a hole in the air, the weave unraveled and vanished. Emarin turned to the rest of them, sweat streaming down his face. "Forming those weaves seemed harder than before," he said.

"waɪ woʊn ðeɪ wɝk?" ɛvɪn sɛd. ðə jʌŋ mænz juθfəl feɪs flʌʃt wɪð æŋɡɝ - əz ɪf ðə pɹɑbləm wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz wɑz ən ɪnsəlt.

"Why won't they work?" Evin said. The young man's youthful face flushed with anger - as if the problem with gateways was an insult.

ænʒɹəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ɑɹmz foʊldəd. ðə tʃɹiz ɹʌsəld, livz ʃɪvɝɪŋ, mɛni fɔlɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bɹaʊn, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔɾəm. ðəɾ ənnɝv hɪm. hid spɛn səm taɪm wɝkɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn dʊɹɪŋ ɪz dʒɝniz ɪn laɪf, ən hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə fɑɹmɝz sɛns fəɹ ɹaɪɾ ən ɹɔŋ ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə lænd.

Androl shook his head, arms folded. The trees rustled, leaves shivering, many falling to the ground. Brown, as if it were autumn. That unnerved him. He'd spent some time working the ground during his journeys in life, and had acquired a farmer's sense for right and wrong regarding the land.

"ju tʃɹaɪ ɪɾ əɡɛn, ænʒɹəl," ɛvɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ ɔlweɪz soʊ ɡʊd wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz."

"You try it again, Androl," Evin said. "You're always so good with gateways."

hi ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝ θɹi. kænlɝ wɑz ði ʌðɝ wʌn ðɛɹ; ði eɪdʒɪŋ ændɔɝən fɑɹmɝ wɔɹ ə dip fɹaʊn. ʌv kɔɹs, kænlɝ ɔfən skaʊld ət wʌn θɪŋ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

He glanced at the other three. Canler was the other one there; the aging Andoran farmer wore a deep frown. Of course, Canler often scowled at one thing or another.

ænʒɹəl kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, ɛmptiɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌv ɔl pæʃənz, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə vɔɪd. seɪɾɪn ʃoʊn ɪn ðɛɹ, laɪf ən paʊɝ. hi sizd ɪt, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz tə ə wɝl ðət wɑz mɔɹ vaɪbɹənt. kəd dɛd plæns lʊk boʊθ sɪkli ən vaɪbɹən ət ðə seɪm taɪm? ə stʃɹeɪnʒ dʒʌkstəpəzɪʃən meɪd pɑsəbəl baɪ seɪɾɪn.

Androl closed his eyes, emptying himself of all passions, embracing the void. Saidin shone in there, life and Power. He seized it, drinking it in. He opened his eyes to a world that was more vibrant. Could dead plants look both sickly and vibrant at the same time? A strange juxtaposition made possible by saidin.

hi foʊkəst. meɪkɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz keɪm soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ tə hɪm ðən ʌðɝ wivz dɪd; hid nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd waɪ. ðoʊ hi kʊdn bɹeɪk ivən ə smɔl ɹɑk əpɑɹt baɪ tʃænəlɪŋ, hi kəd meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə wæɡən tə dʒɹaɪv θɹu. lɑɡən hæd kɔld ɪɾ ɪmpɹɛsɪv; teɪm hæd kɔld ɪɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl.

He focused. Making gateways came so much easier to him than other weaves did; he'd never understood why. Though he couldn't break even a small rock apart by channeling, he could make a gateway large enough for a wagon to drive through. Logain had called it impressive; Taim had called it impossible.

ðɪs taɪm, ænʒɹəl pʊʃt ɔl ə ðə paʊɝ i hæɾ ɪndə hɪz wiv. hi ʌndɝstʊd ɡeɪtweɪz. ðeɪ meɪd sɛns. meɪbi ɪt wɑz ði ɪneɪt fɑndnəs i hæd fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ, fəɹ dɪskʌvɝɪŋ nu pleɪsəz ən nu ɑɹts.

This time, Androl pushed all of the Power he had into his weave. He understood gateways. They made sense. Maybe it was the innate fondness he had for traveling, for discovering new places and new arts.

ðə wivz keɪm təɡɛðɝ. hi dɪdnt noʊɾəs ɛni ʌv ðə dɪfəkəlti ðəɾ əmɝɪn hæd mɛnʃənd.

The weaves came together. He didn't notice any of the difficulty that Emarin had mentioned.

haʊɛvɝ, wən ðə fəmɪljɝ slæʃ ə laɪt ʃəɾ əv kʌm, ðə wiv bɪɡæn tə ənɹævəl ɪnstɛd.

However, when the familiar slash of light should have come, the weave began to unravel instead.

ænʒɹəl tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊl tə ɪt pʊlɪŋ ɪt təɡɛðɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɪt lʊk laɪk ðət wəd wɝk. ðən ðə θɹɛdz slɪd fɹəm ɪz ɡɹɪp, ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ nɛvɝ fɔɹmd.

Androl tried to hold to it pulling it together. For a moment, it looked like that would work. Then the threads slid from his grip, evaporating. The gateway never formed.

"ði ʌðɝ wivz aɪv tʃɹaɪɾ ɔl wɝk," ɛvɪn sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ə ɡloʊb ə laɪt. "ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm."

"The other weaves I've tried all work," Evin said, making a globe of light. "Every one of them."

"oʊnli ɡeɪtweɪz," kænlɝ sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt.

"Only gateways," Canler said with a grunt.

"ɪts laɪk . . ." əmɝɪn sɛd. "ɪts əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ wɑns tə kip əs hɪɹ. ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ."

"It's like . . ." Emarin said. "It's as if something wants to keep us here. In the Black Tower."

"tʃɹaɪ ðɛm ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz ɪnsaɪd ðə pɝɪməɾɝ," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "bʌt tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə lɛɾ ɛni ʌv teɪmz lɔɪəlɪsts si wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ. pɹitɛn tə bi sɝveɪɪŋ, əz teɪm ɔɹɾɝd."

"Try them in other places inside the perimeter," Androl said. "But try not to let any of Taim's loyalists see what you're doing. Pretend to be surveying, as Taim ordered."

ðə mɛn nɑɾəd, ðə θɹi ʌv əm haɪkɪŋ təwɔɹd ði ist. ænʒɹəl lɛf ðə ɡleɪd. nɔɹli wɑz stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd, lʊkɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ hɪm. ðə ʃɔɹt, θɪk-weɪstɪd kɛɹhinɪn mæn weɪvd ən əpɹoʊtʃt. ænʒɹəl mɛɾ ɪm hæfweɪ. nɔɹli hæɾ ən oʊpən, ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ smaɪl. noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ səspɛktəɾ ɪm ə spaɪɪŋ ɑn ðɛm, sʌmθɪŋ ænʒɹəl hæd pʊt tə ɡʊd jus.

The men nodded, the three of them hiking toward the east. Androl left the glade. Norley was standing beside the road, looking about for him. The short, thick-waisted Cairhienin man waved and approached. Androl met him halfway. Norley had an open, inviting smile. Nobody ever suspected him of spying on them, something Androl had put to good use.

"ju spoʊk wɪð mɛzɝ?" ænʒɹəl æskt.

"You spoke with Mezar?" Androl asked.

"ʃʊɹ dɪd," nɔɹli ɹɪplaɪd. "ʃɛɹɾ ə lʌntʃ wɪð hɪm." nɔɹli weɪvd ət mɪʃɹeɪl əz ðeɪ pæst ɪm supɝvaɪzɪŋ ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz pɹæktəsɪŋ ðɛɹ wivz. ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd mæn tɝn əweɪ dɪsmɪsɪvli.

"Sure did," Norley replied. "Shared a lunch with him." Norley waved at Mishraile as they passed him supervising a group of soldiers practicing their weaves. The golden-haired man turned away dismissively.

"ænd?" ænʒɹəl æskt, tɛns.

"And?" Androl asked, tense.

"ɪts nɑt ɹɪli mɛzɝ," nɔɹli sɛd. "oʊ, ɪts mɛzɝz feɪs, ɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf. bʌɾ ɪts nɑt hɪm. aɪ kən si ɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz. tʃɹʌbəl ɪz, wʌtɛvɝ ðə θɪŋ ɪz, ɪts mɛzɝz mɛmɹiz. tɔks ɹaɪt laɪk hɪm. bʌt ðə smaɪl ɪz ɹɔŋ. ɔl ɹɔŋ."

"It's not really Mezar," Norley said. "Oh, it has Mezar's face, right enough. But it's not him. I can see it in his eyes. Trouble is, whatever the thing is, it has Mezar's memories. Talks right like him. But the smile is wrong. All wrong."

ænʒɹəl ʃɪvɝd. "ɪɾ əz tə bi hɪm, nɔɹli."

Androl shivered. "It has to be him, Norley."

"ɪɾ eɪnt. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðæt."

"It ain't. I promise you that."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ɪt dʒʌst eɪnt" ðə staʊt mæn sɛd.

"It just ain't" the stout man said.

ænʒɹəl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. wən mɛzɝ hæd ɹɪtɝn ə fju deɪz bæk - ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðət lɑɡən wɑz wɛl ən ðəɾ ɔl wəd sun bi ɹizɑlvd wɪð teɪm - ænʒɹəl hæd bɪɡʌn tə hoʊp ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðɪs mɛs. bʌt sʌmθɪŋ hæd simd ɔf əbaʊt ðə mæn. bɪɑn ðæt, ðə l hæd meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt ʃoʊ ʌv æksɛptɪŋ mɛzɝ əz ə fʊl æʃəmən; ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd ɹeɪz hɪm. ən naʊ mɛzɝ - wʌns fɪɹsli lɔɪəl tə lɑɡən -  wɑz spɛndɪŋ ɪz taɪm wɪð koʊɾɝən ən teɪmz ʌðɝ lækiz.

Androl took a deep breath. When Mezar had returned a few days back - explaining that Logain was well and that all would soon be resolved with Taim - Androl had begun to hope that there was a way out of this mess. But something had seemed off about the man. Beyond that, the M'Hael had made a great show of accepting Mezar as a full Ashaman; the Dragon had raised him. And now Mezar - once fiercely loyal to Logain -  was spending his time with Coteren and Taim's other lackeys.

"ðɪs ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ bæd, ænʒɹəl," nɔɹli sɛd sɔfli, smaɪlɪŋ ən weɪvɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə pɹæktəsɪŋ mɛn. "aɪd seɪ ɪts taɪm fəɹ əs tə liv hɪɹ, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ ɪts əɡɛnst ɔɹɾɝz."

"This is getting bad, Androl," Norley said softly, smiling and waving toward another group of practicing men. "I'd say it's time for us to leave here, whether or not it's against orders."

"wid nɛvɝ ɡɛt pæs ðoʊz ɡɑɹd poʊsts," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "teɪm woʊn ivən lɛt ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ liv; jə hɝd ðə fɪt ðət plʌmp wʌn θɹu ət ðə ɡeɪts ði ʌðɝ deɪ. teɪm dʌbəlz ðə ɡɑɹɾ ət naɪt, ən ɡeɪtweɪz doʊnt wɝk."

"We'd never get past those guard posts," Androl said. "Taim won't even let those Aes Sedai leave; you heard the fit that plump one threw at the gates the other day. Taim doubles the guard at night, and gateways don't work."

"wɛl, wɪv tə də sʌmθɪŋ, doʊnt wi? aɪ min . . . wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪv ɡɑt lɑɡən? wʌt ðɛn?"

"Well, we have to do something, don't we? I mean . . . what if they've got Logain? What then?"

"aɪ . . ." zi doʊnt noʊ. "ɡoʊ tɔk tə ði ʌðɝz u ɑɹ lɔɪəl tə lɑɡən. aɪm gɑnə muv əs tə ə ʃɛɹd bæɹək. ðɛm ən ðɛɹ fæmliz. wɪl tɛl ðə l ðət wi wɑnə ɡɪv mɔɹ speɪs fəɹ ɪz nu ɹəkɹuts. ðən wɪl poʊst ə ɡɑɹɾ ət naɪts."

"I . . ." Z don't know. "Go talk to the others who are loyal to Logain. I'm going to move us to a shared barrack. Them and their families. We'll tell the M'Hael that we want to give more space for his new recruits. Then we'll post a guard at nights."

"ðæts gɑnə bi ə lɪɾəl ɑbviəs."

"That's going to be a little obvious."

"ðə dɪvɪʒən ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi ɑbviəs," ænʒɹəl sɛd. "ɡoʊ də ɪt."

"The division is already obvious," Androl said. "Go do it."

"ʃʊɹ θɪŋ. bʌt wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

"Sure thing. But what are you going to do?"

ænʒɹəl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪm gɑnə faɪn əs səm ælaɪz."

Androl took a deep breath. "I'm going to find us some allies."
