nɔɹli muvd ɔf tə ðə lɛft, bʌɾ ænʒɹəl kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə pæθ, θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ. ɪt sim ðət fjuɝ ən fjuɝ pipəl wɝ ʃoʊɪŋ ɪm ɹɪspɛk ðiz deɪz. iðɝ ðeɪ wɝ əfɹeɪd tə də soʊ, əɹ ðeɪd θɹoʊn ðɛɹ lɑɾ ɪn wɪð teɪm.

Norley moved off to the left, but Androl continued down the path, through the village. It seemed that fewer and fewer people were showing him respect these days. Either they were afraid to do so, or they'd thrown their lot in with Taim.

pæks ə blæk-koʊɾəd mæn stʊd, wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəd, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ænʒɹəl tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə fil ə tʃɪl.

Packs of black-coated man stood, with arms folded, watching him. Androl tried not to feel a chill.

əz i wɔkt, hi noʊɾəd mɛzɝ - hɛɹ ɡɹeɪɪŋ ət ðə saɪdz, skɪn ə dəmɑni kɑpɝ - stændɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɹup ə lækiz. ðə mæn smaɪld ət hɪm. mɛzɝ hædn ɛvɝ bɪn wʌn u smaɪld izəli. ænʒɹəl nɑɾəd tə hɪm, miɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz.

As he walked, he noted Mezar - hair graying at the sides, skin a Domani copper - standing with a group of lackeys. The man smiled at him. Mezar hadn't ever been one who smiled easily. Androl nodded to him, meeting his eyes.

ən i sɔ wʌt nɔɹli hæd sin. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz dipli ɹɔŋ, sʌmθɪŋ nɑt-kwaɪt-əlaɪv ɪnsaɪd ðoʊz aɪz. ðɪs dɪdn sim tə bi ə mæn, bʌɾ ə pɛɹəɾi ʌv wʌn. ə ʃædoʊ stʌft ɪnsaɪd hjumən skɪn.

And he saw what Norley had seen. Something was deeply wrong, something not-quite-alive inside those eyes. This didn't seem to be a man, but a parody of one. A shadow stuffed inside human skin.

laɪt hɛlp əs ɔl, ænʒɹəl θɔt, hɝiɪŋ baɪ. hi meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə sʌðɝn saɪɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ, tə ə ɡɹup ə smɔl hʌts wɪð blitʃt waɪt wʊd wɔlz ən θætʃt ɹufs ðət niɾəd tə bi ɹipleɪst.

Light help us all, Androl thought, hurrying by. He made his way to the southern side of the village, to a group of small huts with bleached white wood walls and thatched roofs that needed to be replaced.

ænʒɹəl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd aʊtsaɪd. wʌt wɑz i duɪŋ? ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ ðə wɪmən ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wɝ steɪɪŋ. ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪd kʌm tə bɑn ði æʃəmən, bʌt ðeɪ hædn dʌn ɪt soʊ fɑɹ. ðət wɑz ɑbviəsli səm kaɪndə ɹuz. pɝhæps ðeɪd kʌm hɪɹ tə tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə dʒɛntəl ði ɪntaɪɝ lɑt.

Androl hesitated outside. What was he doing? This was where the women of the Red Ajah were staying. They said they'd come to bond the Ashaman, but they hadn't done it so far. That was obviously some kind of ruse. Perhaps they'd come here to try to find a way to gentle the entire lot.

bʌɾ ɪf ðət wɝ ðə keɪs, ðən ət list i kəd kaʊn ɑn əm nɑt saɪɾɪŋ wɪð teɪm. wən jə stɛɹd daʊn ðə ɡʌləɾ ʌv ə laɪənfɪʃ, ə paɪɹəts bɹɪɡ dɪdn sim soʊ bæd. ænʒɹəl hæd hɝd ðə seɪɪŋ wʌns waɪl wɝkɪŋ ə fɪʃɝz boʊɾ ɪn ðə saʊθ.

But if that were the case, then at least he could count on them not siding with Taim. When you stared down the gullet of a lionfish, a pirate's brig didn't seem so bad. Androl had heard the saying once while working a fisher's boat in the south.

teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi nɑkt. ðə plʌmp ɹɛɾ ænsɝd ðə dɔɹ. ʃi hæd ði eɪdʒləs feɪs ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ - nɑt jʌŋ, ɹɪli, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ nɑɾ oʊld. ʃi aɪd hɪm.

Taking a deep breath, he knocked. The plump Red answered the door. She had the ageless face of an Aes Sedai - not young, really, but also not old. She eyed him.

"aɪ hɪɹ jə wɑnə liv ðə blæk taʊɝ," ænʒɹəl sɛd, hoʊpɪŋ i wɑz duɪŋ ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ.

"I hear you want to leave the Black Tower," Androl said, hoping he was doing the right thing.

"hæz jəɹ l tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪnd?" ʃi æskt, saʊndɪŋ hoʊpfəl. ʃi æktʃəli  smaɪld. ə ɹɛɹ ækʃən fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"Has your M'Hael changed his mind?" she asked, sounding hopeful. She actually smiled. A rare action for an Aes Sedai.

"noʊ," ænʒɹəl sɛd, "soʊ fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ, hi stɪl fɝbɪdz jə tə liv."

"No," Androl said, "so far as I know, he still forbids you to leave."

ʃi fɹaʊnd. "ðɛn - "

She frowned. "Then - "

ænʒɹəl loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "jɔɹ nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u wəd laɪk tə liv ðɪs pleɪs, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Androl lowered his voice. "You're not the only one who would like to leave this place, Aes Sedai."

ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm, hɝ feɪs bɪkʌmɪŋ pɝfəkli kɑm. ʃi dʌzn tʃɹʌs mi, hi θɔt. ɑd, haʊ ðə mɪɹ læk ʌv ɪmoʊʃən kəɾ ɪtsɛlf kənveɪ minɪŋ.

She looked at him, her face becoming perfectly calm. She doesn't trust me, he thought. Odd, how the mere lack of emotion could itself convey meaning.

dɛspɹɪt, hi tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ðə fɹeɪm ə ðə dɔɹ. "sʌmθɪŋz ɹɔŋ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs. sʌmθɪŋ wɝs ðən jə ʌndɝstænd. wʌns, lɔŋ əɡoʊ, mɛn ən wɪmən u wɝk ðə paʊɝ stʃɹoʊv təɡɛðɝ. ðeɪ wɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ fəɹ ɪt. pliz. hɪɹ mi aʊt."

Desperate, he took a step forward, laying a hand on the frame of the door. "Something's wrong in this place. Something worse than you understand. Once, long ago, men and women who worked the Power strove together. They were stronger for it. Please. Hear me out."

ʃi stʊd fəɹ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ, ðən pʊl ðə dɔɹ oʊpən. "kʌm ɪn, kwɪkli. tɑɹnə - ðə wʊmən aɪ ʃɛɹ ðɪs hʌt wɪð - ɪz əweɪ. wi mʌs bi dʌn bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹɪtɝnz."

She stood for a moment longer, then pulled the door open. "Come in, quickly. Tarna - the woman I share this hut with - is away. We must be done before she returns."

ænʒɹəl stɛpt ʌp ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ. hi dɪdnt noʊ wɛðɝ i wɑz stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə paɪɹəts bɹɪɡ əɹ ðə laɪənfɪʃəz maʊθ. bʌɾ ɪt wəɾ əv tə du.

Androl stepped up into the building. He didn't know whether he was stepping into the pirate's brig or the lionfish's mouth. But it would have to do.


tʃæptɝ fɪftisɛvən


CHAPTER 57

eɪ ɹæbət fəɹ sʌpɝ


A Rabbit for Supper

eɪ ɹæbət fəɹ sʌpɝ mæt hɪɾ ənivən ɡɹaʊnd, blaɪndɪd baɪ ðə flæʃ ə laɪt. kɝsɪŋ, hi juz ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ tə stɛɾi hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə spɹɪŋi ɝθ. hi smɛl foʊlɪdʒ, dɝɾ ən ɹɑɾɪŋ wʊd. ɪnsɛks bʌzd ɪn ðə ʃeɪd.

A Rabbit for Supper Mat hit uneven ground, blinded by the flash of light. Cursing, he used the ashandarei to steady himself on the springy earth. He smelled foliage, dirt and rotting wood. Insects buzzed in the shade.

ðə waɪtnəs feɪɾəd, ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. hi hæd hæf- ɪkspɛktəd tə ɹiəpɪɹ ɪn ɹɪɾiən. ɪt sim ðət ðə spɪɹ ɹɪtɝn ɪm tə hɪz wɝld ɪn ðə pleɪs wɛɹ i hæɾ ɛntɝd. tɑm sæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, pɹɑpɪŋ ʌp mɔɪɹeɪn, hu wɑz blɪŋkɪŋ ən lʊkɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ.

The whiteness faded, and he found himself standing outside the Tower of Ghenjei. He had half- expected to reappear in Rhuidean. It seemed that the spear returned him to his world in the place where he had entered. Thom sat on the ground, propping up Moiraine, who was blinking and looking about her.

mæt spʌn ɑn ðə taʊɝ ən pɔɪntəɾ ʌpwɝd. "aɪ noʊ jəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ!" hi sɛd, θɹɪld. hi hæd meɪɾ ɪt. hi hæd blʌɾi meɪɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ əlaɪv! "aɪ bit ju, jə kɹʌsti but-livɪŋz! aɪ, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən, sɝvaɪv jəɹ tʃɹæps! hɑ!" hi ɹeɪz ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. "æn jə ɡeɪv mi ðə weɪ aʊt!

Mat spun on the tower and pointed upward. "I know you're watching!" he said, thrilled. He had made it. He had bloody made it out alive! "I beat you, you crusty boot-leavings! I, Matrim Cauthon, survived your traps! Ha!" He raised the ashandarei over his head. "And you gave me the way out!

tʃu ɑn ðət bɪɾɝnəs fəɹ lʌntʃ, jə fleɪmɪŋ, bɝnɪŋ, mɪsbəɡɑɾən laɪɝz!"

Chew on that bitterness for lunch, you flaming, burning, misbegotten liars!"

mæt bimd, slæmɪŋ ðə spɪɹ daʊn bʌt fɝst ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm. hi nɑɾəd. noʊbɑdi ɡɑt ðə bɛɾɝ ə meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. ðeɪ hæd laɪd tə hɪm, toʊld ɪm veɪɡ pɹɑfəsiz ən θɹɛɾənd hɪm, ən ðən ðeɪ hæd hæŋ hɪm. bʌt mæt keɪm aʊɾ əhɛɾ ɪn ði ɛnd.

Mat beamed, slamming the spear down butt first onto the ground beside him. He nodded. Nobody got the better of Matrim Cauthon. They had lied to him, told him vague prophecies and threatened him, and then they had hanged him. But Mat came out ahead in the end.

"hu wɑz ði ʌðɝ?" mɔɪɹeɪnz sɑf vɔɪs æsk fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "ðə wʌn aɪ sɔ, bʌt dɪd nɑt noʊ?"

"Who was the other?" Moiraine's soft voice asked from behind. "The one I saw, but did not know?"

"hi dɪdn meɪk ɪɾ aʊt," tɑm sɛd sɑmbɝli.

"He didn't make it out," Thom said somberly.

ðət dæmpən mæts spɪɹəts. ðɛɹ vɪktɝi hæd kʌm əɾ ə pɹaɪs, ə tɛɹəbəl wʌn. mæt bɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ə lɛdʒən ɔl ðɪs taɪm?

That dampened Mat's spirits. Their victory had come at a price, a terrible one. Mat been traveling with a legend all this time?

"hi wɑz ə fɹɛnd," θɔɹn sɛd sɔfli.

"He was a friend," Thorn said softly.

"hi wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt mæn," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ən pʊlɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd plæntəɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə dɝt. "wɛn jə ɹaɪt ðə bæləɾ ʌv ɔl ðɪs, tɑm, meɪk ʃʊɹ jə pɔɪn aʊt ðəɾ i wɑz ðə hɪɹoʊ."

"He was a great man," Mat said, turning and pulling his ashandarei from where he had planted it in the dirt. "When you write the ballad of all this, Thom, make sure you point out that he was the hero."

θɔɹn ɡlænst ət mæt, ðən nɑɾəd noʊɪŋli. "ðə wɝld wɪl wɑnə noʊ wʌt hæpən tə ðət mæn." laɪt. əz mæt θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt tɑm hæd nɑt bɪn əɾ ɔl sɝpɹaɪz tə hɪɹ noʊl wɑz dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ. hi hæd noʊn. wən hæɾ i fɪɡjɝɾ ɪɾ aʊt? waɪ hæɾ i sɛd nʌθɪŋ tə mæt? səm fɹɛn tɑm wɑz.

Thorn glanced at Mat, then nodded knowingly. "The world will want to know what happened to that man." Light. As Mat thought about it Thom had not been at all surprised to hear Noal was Jain Farstrider. He had known. When had he figured it out? Why had he said nothing to Mat? Some friend Thom was.

mæt dʒʌst ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wɛl, wɝ aʊt, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. bʌt tɑm, nɛks taɪm aɪ wɑnə də ðə blʌɾi nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ, snik ʌp bɪhaɪn ən hɪt mi ɑn ðə hɛd wɪð sʌmθɪŋ lɑɹdʒ, hɛvi ən blʌnt.

Mat just shook his head. "Well, we're out, one way or another. But Thom, next time I want to do the bloody negotiating, sneak up behind and hit me on the head with something large, heavy and blunt.

ðən teɪk oʊvɝ."

Then take over."

"jɔɹ ɹɪkwɛst ɪz noʊɾəd."

"Your request is noted."

"lɛts muv ɑn ə lɪɾəl weɪ. aɪ doʊn laɪk ðət blʌɾi taʊɝ lumɪŋ oʊvɝ mi."

"Let's move on a little way. I don't like that bloody tower looming over me."

"jɛs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "ju kəd seɪ ðət ðeɪ fiɾ ɔf ɪmoʊʃən. ðoʊ aɪ wʊdn kɔl ɪt 'fiɾɪŋ ɔf soʊ mʌtʃ əz 'dɪlaɪɾɪŋ ɪn' ɪmoʊʃən. ðeɪ doʊnt niɾ ɪt tə sɝvaɪv, bʌɾ ɪt plizɪz əm ɡɹeɪtli."

"Yes," Moiraine said, "you could say that they feed off emotion. Though I wouldn't call it 'feeding off so much as 'delighting in' emotion. They don't need it to survive, but it pleases them greatly."

ðeɪ sæɾ ɪn ə wʊɾɪd hɑloʊ ə ʃɔɹt wɔk fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, nɛks tə ðə mɛdoʊ bɪsaɪd ði ɑɹɪnɛl. ðə θɪk tʃɹi kænəpi kul ði ɛɹ ən əbskjʊɹd ðɛɹ vju ʌv ðə taʊɝ.

They sat in a wooded hollow a short walk from the tower, next to the meadow beside the Arinelle. The thick tree canopy cooled the air and obscured their view of the tower.

mæt sæɾ ɑn ə smɔl, mɔsi boʊldɝ əz tɑm meɪɾ ə faɪɝ. hi hæɾ ə fju ʌv ɑlʌdʒɹəz stʃɹaɪkɝz ɪn ɪz pɑkəɾ əz wɛl əz səm pækɪts ə ti, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə wɔɹm ðə wɔɾɝ ɪn.

Mat sat on a small, mossy boulder as Thom made a fire. He had a few of Aludra's strikers in his pocket as well as some packets of tea, though there was nothing to warm the water in.

mɔɪɹeɪn sæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, stɪl ɹæpt ɪn θɔɹnz kloʊk, linɪŋ bæk əɡɛnst ə fɔlən lɔɡ. ʃi hɛl ðə kloʊk kloʊz fɹəm ði ɪnsaɪd, lɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɪnvɛləp əɹ kəmplitli, seɪv fəɹ əɹ feɪs ən ðoʊz dɑɹk kɝlz. ʃi lʊk mɔɹ ə wʊmən ðən mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd - ɪn ɪz mɛmɹiz, ʃi wɑz laɪk ə stætʃu.

Moiraine sat on the ground, still wrapped in Thorn's cloak, leaning back against a fallen log. She held the cloak closed from the inside, letting it envelop her completely, save for her face and those dark curls. She looked more a woman than Mat remembered - in his memories, she was like a statue.

ɔlweɪz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, feɪs laɪk pɑlɪʃt stoʊn, aɪz laɪk dɑɹk bɹaʊn toʊpæz.

Always expressionless, face like polished stone, eyes like dark brown topaz.

naʊ ʃi sæt wɪð peɪl skɪn, flʌʃt tʃiks, hɛɹ kɝld ən fɔlɪŋ nætʃɹəli ɝaʊn əɹ feɪs. ʃi wɑz fɛtʃɪŋ, seɪv fəɹ ðəɾ eɪdʒləs ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs. jɛt ðət feɪs ʃoʊd fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪmoʊʃən ðən mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd, ə lʊk ə fɑndnəs wən ʃi ɡlænst ət tɑm, ə feɪnt ʃɪvɝ wən ʃi spoʊk ə hɝ taɪm ɪn ðə taʊɝ.

Now she sat with pale skin, flushed cheeks, hair curled and falling naturally around her face. She was fetching, save for that ageless Aes Sedai face. Yet that face showed far more emotion than Mat remembered, a look of fondness when she glanced at Thom, a faint shiver when she spoke of her time in the tower.

ʃi ɡlænst ət mæt, ən əɹ aɪz wɝ stɪl əpɹeɪzɪŋ. jɛs, ðɪs wɑz ðə seɪm mɔɪɹeɪn.

She glanced at Mat, and her eyes were still appraising. Yes, this was the same Moiraine.

hʌmbəld, kæs daʊn. ðət meɪɾ əɹ sim stʃɹɔŋɝ tə hɪm fəɹ səm ɹizən.

Humbled, cast down. That made her seem stronger to him for some reason.

θɔɹn blu əɾ ə hɛzɪɾənt fleɪm ðət kɝld ə lɑk ə smoʊk ɪndə ði ɛɹ bɪfɔɹ flɪkɝɪŋ aʊt. ðə wʊd wɑz pɹɑbli tu wɛt. θɔɹn kɝst.

Thorn blew at a hesitant flame that curled a lock of smoke into the air before flickering out. The wood was probably too wet. Thorn cursed.

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt, tɑm," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ wɪl bi wɛl."

"It's all right, Thom," Moiraine said softly. "I will be well."

"aɪ woʊn əv jə kætʃɪŋ koʊl ðə moʊmənt wi fɹi jə fɹəm ðət pleɪs" tɑm sɛd. hi ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə stʃɹaɪkɝ, bʌt sʌɾənli ðə wʊd spɑɹkt, ən ðən faɪɝ spʌɾɝd tə laɪf əz ɪt kənsum ðə tu-wɛt tɪndɝ.

"I won't have you catching cold the moment we free you from that place" Thom said. He got out a striker, but suddenly the wood sparked, and then fire sputtered to life as it consumed the too-wet tinder.

mæt ɡlænst ət mɔɪɹeɪn, hu hæɾ ə lʊk ə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Mat glanced at Moiraine, who had a look of concentration on her face.

"oʊ," tɑm sɛd, ðən tʃʌkəld. "aɪd fɝɡɑɾən əbaʊt ðæt, nɪɹli. . . ."

"Oh," Thom said, then chuckled. "I'd forgotten about that, nearly. . . ."

"ɪts ɔl aɪ kən mænədʒ naʊ ɑn maɪ oʊn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. laɪt, hæd mɔɪɹeɪn ɡɹɪməs bɪfɔɹ? ʃi bɪn tu haɪ-ænd-maɪɾi fəɹ ðæt, hæd ʃi nɑt? əɹ wɑz mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ əɹ ɹɔŋ?

"It's all I can manage now on my own," Moiraine said, grimacing. Light, had Moiraine grimaced before? She been too high-and-mighty for that, had she not? Or was Mat remembering her wrong?

mɔɪɹeɪn. hi wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə fleɪmɪŋ ɑlwɹeɪnɛl ðoʊ hi hæd ɡɔn ɪndə ðə taʊɝ wɪð ðə dɪstɪŋk pɝpəs ə ɹɛskjuɪŋ hɝ, ɪt simd ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ðəɾ i wɑz spikɪŋ wɪð hɝ. ɪt wɑz laɪk tɔkɪŋ tə . . .

Moiraine. He was talking to flaming Aloirainel Though he had gone into the tower with the distinct purpose of rescuing her, it seemed incredible that he was speaking with her. It was like talking to . . .

wɛl, laɪk tɔkɪŋ tə bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ əɹ dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ. mæt smaɪld, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. wʌɾ ə wɝl ðɪs wɑz, ən wʌɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pleɪs i hæɾ ɪn ɪt.

Well, like talking to Birgitte Silverbow or Jain Farstrider. Mat smiled, shaking his head. What a world this was, and what a strange place he had in it.

"wʌt dɪd jə min baɪ ðæt, mɔɪɹeɪn?" tɑm æskt, nɝtʃɝɪŋ ðə faɪɝ wɪð səm stɪks. "ɪts ɔl jə kən mænədʒ?"

"What did you mean by that, Moiraine?" Thom asked, nurturing the fire with some sticks. "It's all you can manage?"

"ði æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn," ʃi ɪkspleɪnd, vɔɪs kɑm. "ðeɪ seɪvɝ ən ɹɛlɪʃ paʊɝfəl ɪmoʊʃənz.

"The Aelfinn and Eelfinn," she explained, voice calm. "They savor and relish powerful emotions.

fəɹ səm ɹizən ði ɪfɛks ʌv ə tɑvɝən ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ ɪntɑksɪkeɪɾɪŋ tə ðɛm. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðət ðeɪ ɛndʒɔɪ."

For some reason the effects of a ta'veren are even more intoxicating to them. There are other things that they enjoy."

tɑm ɡlænst ət hɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

Thom glanced at her, frowning.

"maɪ paʊɝ, tɑm," ʃi ɪkspleɪnd. "aɪ kəd hɪɹ əm bɑɹkɪŋ ən hɪsɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ðeɪ fɛɾ ɑn mi, boʊθ æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn ɪn tɝn. ðeɪv nɑɾ ɔfən hæɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ðɛmsɛlvz, ɪt simz. waɪl dʒɹeɪnɪŋ maɪ əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl, ðeɪ wɝ fɛd tufoʊld - maɪ sɑɹoʊ ət wʌɾ aɪ wɑz luzɪŋ ən ðə paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. maɪ kəpæsəɾi hæz bɪn ɡɹeɪtli ɹədust.

"My Power, Thom," she explained. "I could hear them barking and hissing to one another as they fed on me, both Aelfinn and Eelfinn in turn. They have not often had an Aes Sedai to themselves, it seems. While draining my ability to channel, they were fed twofold - my sorrow at what I was losing and the Power itself. My capacity has been greatly reduced.

"ðeɪ kleɪm tə hæv kɪld lænfɝ baɪ dʒɹeɪnɪŋ əɹ tu kwɪkli, ðoʊ aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ meɪ hæv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk mi əfɹeɪd. ə mæn wɑz ðəɹ wʌns, wən ðeɪ woʊk mi. hi sɛɾ aɪ wɑz nɑt ðə wʌn i wɑntəd." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃɪvɝd. "səmtaɪmz aɪ wɪʃt ðət ðeɪ wəd dʒɹeɪn mi kwɪkli ən ɛn maɪ laɪf."

"They claimed to have killed Lanfear by draining her too quickly, though I think they may have been trying to make me afraid. A man was there once, when they woke me. He said I was not the one he wanted." She hesitated, then shivered. "Sometimes I wished that they would drain me quickly and end my life."

ðə smɔl kæmp ɡɹu saɪlən seɪv fəɹ ðə pɑpɪŋ ə ðə faɪɝ. tɑm lʊk təwɔɹd mɔɪɹeɪn, simɪŋ hɛlpləs.

The small camp grew silent save for the popping of the fire. Thom looked toward Moiraine, seeming helpless.

"du nɑt ʃoʊ mi sətʃ sɑɹoʊ, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ hæv fɛl tɛɹəbəl θɪŋz, bʌɾ ɔl pipəl noʊ sətʃ moʊməns ə dɪspɛɹ. aɪ bɪliv ðət jə wəd kʌm." ʃi ɹimuvd əɹ hæn fɹəm ðə kloʊk - ɹɪvilɪŋ ə slɛndɝ, peɪl ʃoʊldɝ ən kɑlɝboʊn - ən ɹitʃt təwɔɹd hɪm. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən tʊk ðə hæn ən skwizd ɪt.

"Do not show me such sorrow, Thom Merrilin," Moiraine said, smiling. "I have felt terrible things, but all people know such moments of despair. I believed that you would come." She removed her hand from the cloak - revealing a slender, pale shoulder and collarbone - and reached toward him. He hesitated, then took the hand and squeezed it.

mɔɪɹeɪn lʊk tə mæt. "æn ju, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. nɑɾ ə sɪmpəl fɑɹm læɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. dʌz jəɹ aɪ peɪn jə mʌtʃ?"

Moiraine looked to Mat. "And you, Matrim Cauthon. Not a simple farm lad any longer. Does your eye pain you much?"

mæt ʃɹʌɡd.

Mat shrugged.

"aɪ wəd hil ðə waʊn ɪf aɪ kʊd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ivən wɝ aɪ stɪl əz stʃɹɔŋ əz aɪ wʌns wɑz, aɪ kʊdn ɹɪstɔɹ jəɹ aɪ." ʃi lʊk daʊn ɹilisɪŋ θɔɹnz hæn ən hoʊldɪŋ ʌp əɹ ɑɹm.

"I would Heal the wound if I could," Moiraine said. "But even were I still as strong as I once was, I couldn't restore your eye." She looked down releasing Thorn's hand and holding up her arm.

"du juv ði æŋɡɹil?"

"Do you have the angreal?"

"oʊ, jɛs," θɔɹn sɛd, fɪʃɪŋ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ bɹeɪsləɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz pɑkət. hi pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn əɹ ɑɹm.

"Oh, yes," Thorn said, fishing the strange bracelet out of his pocket. He put it on her arm.

"wɪð ðɪs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɪl bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ət lis teɪk ðə peɪn əweɪ. ðeɪ pleɪst ɪɾ ɑn mi tə lemi dʒɹɔ mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ, tə meɪk ðɛɹ fiɾɪŋ mɔɹ sʌkjəlɪnt. aɪ æsk fəɹ ɪt, æktʃəli , əz wʌn ə maɪ θɹi dɪmænz. aɪ dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wəɾ ɛn ʌp juzɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛns mi."

"With this," Moiraine said. "I will be strong enough to at least take the pain away. They placed it on me to let me draw more of the Power, to make their feeding more succulent. I asked for it, actually, as one of my three demands. I did not realize they would end up using it against me."

"ðeɪ ɡeɪv jə jəɹ θɹi dɪmænz?" mæt æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"They gave you your three demands?" Mat asked, frowning.

"aɪ pæs θɹu ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil" ʃi sɛd. "ði eɪntʃən tʃɹiɾi hɛl fəɹ boʊθ ʌv ʌs, ðoʊ wɪð ðə dɔɹweɪ dɪstʃɹɔɪd, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɪmpəl ɹɪtɝn. aɪ nu fɹəm . . . pɹiviəs ɪvɛns ðəɾ aɪ wəd nɑɾ ɪskeɪp ənlɛs jə keɪm fəɹ mi, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt maɪ dɪmænz wɝ əɹ haʊ kɛɹfəli aɪ wɝɾɪd ðɛm. soʊ aɪ juzd əm fəɹ ðə bɛst."

"I passed through the ter'angreal" she said. "The ancient treaty held for both of us, though with the doorway destroyed, there was no simple return. I knew from . . . previous events that I would not escape unless you came for me, no matter what my demands were or how carefully I worded them. So I used them for the best."

"wʌt dɪd jə æsk fɔɹ?" mæt æskt. "bɪɑn ði æŋɡɹil?"

"What did you ask for?" Mat asked. "Beyond the angreal?"

ʃi smaɪld. "aɪ ʃæl kip ðət tə maɪsɛlf, fəɹ naʊ. jə də hæv maɪ θæŋks, jʌŋ meɪtʃɹim. fəɹ maɪ laɪf."

She smiled. "I shall keep that to myself, for now. You do have my thanks, young Matrim. For my life."

"ðɛn aɪ ɡɛs wɝ ikwəl," hi sɛd. "ju seɪv mi fɹəm laɪf ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. bɝn mi ɪf aɪ hævən hæɾ ə naɪs ɡæləp ʌv ɪt sɪns ðɛn."

"Then I guess we're equal," he said. "You saved me from life in the Two Rivers. Burn me if I haven't had a nice gallop of it since then."

"æn jəɹ waʊnd?"

"And your wound?"

"dʌzn hɝt soʊ mʌtʃ." æktʃəli , ɪt θɹɑbd. ɹɪli, ɹɪli bædli. "noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə weɪst stʃɹɛŋkθ ɑn ɪt."

"Doesn't hurt so much." Actually, it throbbed. Really, really badly. "No need for you to waste strength on it."

"stɪl əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, aɪ si."

"Still afraid of the One Power, I see."

hi bɹɪsəld. "əfɹeɪd?"

He bristled. "Afraid?"

"aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk juv ɡʊd ɹizən fəɹ ðət wɛɹinɪs." ʃi lʊkt əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. "bʌt teɪk kɛɹ. ðə moʊs dɪsplisɪŋ ʌv ɪvɛns ɪn əɹ laɪvz ɑɹ səmtaɪmz fəɹ əɹ ɡʊd."

"I should think you have good reason for that wariness." She looked away from him. "But take care. The most displeasing of events in our lives are sometimes for our good."

jɛs, ʃi wɑz stɪl mɔɪɹeɪn. kwɪk wɪð ə mɔɹəl ən ædvaɪs. bʌt pɝhæps ʃi hæɾ ə ɹaɪt - æftɝ wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn θɹu - tə lɛktʃɝ ɑn sʌfɝɪŋ. laɪt! ʃi hæd noʊn wʌt ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɡoʊ θɹu, ən jɛt ʃi hæd stɪl pʊld lænfɝ ɪndə ðət tɛɹæŋɡɹil? meɪbi mæt wɑz nɑt ðə hɪɹoʊ hɪɹ, ən meɪbi noʊl wɑz nɑɾ iðɝ.

Yes, she was still Moiraine. Quick with a moral and advice. But perhaps she had a right - after what she had been through - to lecture on suffering. Light! She had known what she would have to go through, and yet she had still pulled Lanfear into that ter'angreal? Maybe Mat was not the hero here, and maybe Noal was not either.

"soʊ wʌt naʊ?" θɔɹn sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑn ə stʌmp. ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə faɪɝ dɪd fil ɡʊd.

"So what now?" Thorn said, settling back on a stump. The warmth of the fire did feel good.

"aɪ mʌs faɪn ɹænd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "hi wɪl nid maɪ hɛlp. aɪ tʃɹʌs hiz dʌn wɛl ɪn maɪ æbsəns?"

"I must find Rand," Moiraine said. "He will need my help. I trust he has done well in my absence?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðæt," mæt sɛd. "hiz hæf mæɾ ən ðə hoʊl blʌɾi wɝld ɪz ət wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts." kʌlɝz swɝld. ɹænd iɾɪŋ ə mil wɪð mɪn. mæt dɪspɛl ði ɪmədʒ.

"I don't know about that," Mat said. "He's half mad and the whole bloody world is at one another's throats." Colors swirled. Rand eating a meal with Min. Mat dispelled the image.

ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

She raised an eyebrow.

"bʌt," mæt æknɑlɪdʒd, "hiz ɡɑt moʊst ɛvɹibɑɾi pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd ðə læs bæɾəl. ən vɛɹɪn sɛz i mænədʒ tə klin ðə teɪn fɹəm seɪɾɪn."

"But," Mat acknowledged, "he's got most everybody pointed toward the Last Battle. And Verin says he managed to clean the taint from saidin."

"blɛsɪd laɪt," mɔɪɹeɪn wɪspɝd. "haʊ?"

"Blessed Light," Moiraine whispered. "How?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ."

"I don't know."

"ðɪs tʃeɪnʒəz ɛvɹiθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, smaɪl dipənɪŋ. "hi hæz fɪkst wʌɾ i wʌns sɛt ɹɔŋ. 'baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən keɪm əɹ peɪn, ən baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑz ðə waʊn ɹɪpɛɹd.'"

"This changes everything," she said, smile deepening. "He has fixed what he once set wrong. 'By the Dragon came our pain, and by the Dragon was the wound repaired.'"

"mæt kips seɪɪŋ wi ʃəd bi hævɪŋ ə fɛstəvəl əɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə sɛləbɹeɪt," θɔɹn noʊɾəd.

"Mat keeps saying we should be having a festival or something to celebrate," Thorn noted.

"ðoʊ meɪbi hi oʊnli wɑns ə ɡʊɾ ɪkskjus tə ɡɛt dʒɹʌŋk."

"Though maybe he only wants a good excuse to get drunk."

"aɪd seɪ ðæts ə sɝɾənti," mæt æɾəd. "ɛniweɪ, ɹændz bɪn bɪzi. ɪleɪn sɛz hiz ɡɑt səm kaɪndə miɾɪŋ ɝeɪnʒd wɪð ðə mɑnɑɹks ʌndɝ ɪm kʌmɪŋ ʌp sun."

"I'd say that's a certainty," Mat added. "Anyway, Rand's been busy. Elayne says he's got some kind of meeting arranged with the monarchs under him coming up soon."

"ɪleɪn ɪz kwin, ðɛn?"

"Elayne is Queen, then?"

"ʃʊɹ ɪz. hɝ mʌðɝ wɑz kɪl baɪ ɹɑvɪn," mæt sɛd.

"Sure is. Her mother was killed by Rahvin," Mat said.

"soʊ jə toʊl mi."

"So you told me."

"aɪ dɪd? wɛn?"

"I did? When?"

"ə laɪftaɪm əɡoʊ, meɪtʃɹim," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd, smaɪlɪŋ.

"A lifetime ago, Matrim," she replied, smiling.

"oʊ. wɛl, ɹænd fɪnɪʃt ɪm ɔf. soʊ ðæts ɡʊd."

"Oh. Well, Rand finished him off. So that's good."

"æn ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt.

"And the other Forsaken?" Moiraine asked.

"doʊnt noʊ," mæt sɛd.

"Don't know," Mat said.

"mæts bɪn tu bɪzi tə kip tʃɹæk," tɑm æɾəd. "hiz bɪn spɛndɪŋ ɪz taɪm mɛɹiɪŋ ði ɛmpɹɛs ə ðə sintʃæn."

"Mat's been too busy to keep track," Thom added. "He's been spending his time marrying the Empress of the Seanchan."

mɔɪɹeɪn blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "ju dɪd wʌt?"

Moiraine blinked in surprise. "You did what?"

"ɪt wɑz ən æksəɾənt," mæt sɛd leɪmli, hʌntʃɪŋ daʊn.

"It was an accident," Mat said lamely, hunching down.

"ju æksədɛntəli mɛɹid ðə sintʃæn ɛmpɹɛs?"

"You accidentally married the Seanchan Empress?"

"ðeɪv ɡɑt səm ɑd kʌstəmz," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæt daʊn. "stʃɹeɪnʒ foʊk." hi fɔɹst aʊɾ ə tʃʌkəl.

"They've got some odd customs," Mat said, pulling his hat down. "Strange folk." He forced out a chuckle.

"tɑvɝən" mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd.

"Ta'veren" Moiraine said.

sʌmhaʊ, hi hæd noʊn ʃi wəd seɪ ðæt. laɪt. wɛl, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hæv əɹ bæk. mæt wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ stʃɹɔŋli hi fɛl ðæt. hu wʊɾə θɔɾ ɪt? əfɛkʃən fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, fɹəm hɪm?

Somehow, he had known she would say that. Light. Well, it was good to have her back. Mat was surprised at how strongly he felt that. Who would have thought it? Affection for an Aes Sedai, from him?

"wɛl," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ kən si ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni teɪlz aɪ nid tə bi toʊld. bʌt fəɹ naʊ, wɪl nid tə sik aʊt ɹænd."

"Well," she said, "I can see there are many tales I need to be told. But for now, we will need to seek out Rand."

hi hæɾ ɔlsoʊ noʊn ðət ʃi wəd tʃɹaɪ tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ. "ju faɪn ɪm mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌɾ aɪv ɡɑt θɪŋz tə də ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. doʊn min tə ɑɹɡju ən ɔl, bʌt ðæts ðə fækt ʌv ɪt. jə ʃəd kʌm ðɛɹ, tu.

He had also known that she would try to take charge. "You find him Moiraine, but I've got things to do in Caemlyn. Don't mean to argue and all, but that's the fact of it. You should come there, too.

ɪleɪnz mɔɹ laɪkli ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls tə bi eɪbəl tə hɛlp jə wɪð ɹænd."

Elayne's more likely than anyone else to be able to help you with Rand."

blʌɾi kʌlɝz. əz ɪf hævɪŋ wʌn aɪ wɝ nɑt bæɾ ɪnʌf, hi hæd ðoʊz fleɪmɪŋ vɪʒənz bʌntʃɪŋ ʌp ɪz saɪɾ ɛvɹi taɪm i soʊ mʌtʃ əz θɔɾ ə ɹæn -  bɝn ðoʊz vɪʒənz!

Bloody colors. As if having one eye were not bad enough, he had those flaming visions bunching up his sight every time he so much as thought of Ran -  Burn those visions!

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ əz i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðən blʌʃt. hi pɹɑbli lʊk laɪk i wɑz hævɪŋ ə fɪt.

Moiraine raised an eyebrow as he shook his head, then blushed. He probably looked like he was having a fit.

"wi ʃæl si, meɪtʃɹim," ʃi sɛd, ðən ɡlænst ət θɔɹn, hu stʊd hoʊldɪŋ ðə pækɪts ə ti.

"We shall see, Matrim," she said, then glanced at Thorn, who stood holding the packets of tea.

mæt hæf θɔɾ i wəd tʃɹaɪ tə bɔɪl wɔɾɝ ɪn ɪz oʊn hænz, ɪf oʊnli tə ɡɛt səm wɔɹm ti fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn. θɔɹn lʊkt ət hɝ, ən ʃi hɛld aʊɾ əɹ hæn əɡɛn.

Mat half thought he would try to boil water in his own hands, if only to get some warm tea for Moiraine. Thorn looked at her, and she held out her hand again.

"dɪɹəs θɔɹn," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ wəɾ əv jə fəɹ ə hʌzbənd, ɪf jəl əv mi fəɹ ə waɪf."

"Dearest Thorn," she said. "I would have you for a husband, if you'll have me for a wife."

"wʌt?" mæt sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp. hi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɪz fɔɹhɛd, nɪɹli nɑkɪŋ ɪz hæt fɹi.

"What?" Mat said, standing up. He raised a hand to his forehead, nearly knocking his hat free.

"wʌt dɪd jə seɪ?"

"What did you say?"

"hʌʃ, mæt," θɔɹn sɛd. hi dɪd nɑt teɪk mɔɪɹeɪnz ɔfɝd hænd. "ju noʊ aɪv nɛvɝ mʌtʃ laɪkt wɪmən u kən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, mɔɪɹeɪn. jə noʊ ɪt hɛl mi bæk ɪn ðə pæst."

"Hush, Mat," Thorn said. He did not take Moiraine's offered hand. "You know I've never much liked women who can channel the One Power, Moiraine. You know it held me back in the past."

"aɪ doʊn əv mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ naʊ, dɪɹəs θɔɹn. wɪθaʊt ðɪs æn-ɡɹil, aɪ wʊdn bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi ɹeɪzd æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əl θɹoʊ ɪɾ əweɪ, ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪɾ ə mi." ʃi lɪftəɾ aʊɾ əɹ ʌðɝ hænd, bɛɹli steɪɪŋ mɑɾəst. ʃi pʊld ɔf ði æŋɡɹil.

"I don't have much of the Power now, dearest Thorn. Without this an-greal, I wouldn't be strong enough to be raised Accepted in the White Tower. I will throw it away, if you wish it of me." She lifted out her other hand, barely staying modest. She pulled off the angreal.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk soʊ, mɔɪɹeɪn," θɔɹn sɛd, nilɪŋ daʊn, teɪkɪŋ əɹ hænz. "noʊ, aɪ woʊn ɹɑb jə ʌv ɛniθɪŋ."

"I don't think so, Moiraine," Thorn said, kneeling down, taking her hands. "No, I won't rob you of anything."

"bʌt wɪð ɪɾ əl bi vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ, stʃɹɔŋɝ ɪn ðə paʊɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɑz teɪkən."

"But with it I'll be very strong, stronger in the Power than before I was taken."

"soʊ bi ɪt, ðɛn," hi sɛd. hi pʊt ðə bɹeɪslət bæk ɑn əɹ ɹɪst. "aɪl mɛɹi jə naʊ, ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt."

"So be it, then," he said. He put the bracelet back on her wrist. "I'll marry you now, if you wish it."

ʃi smaɪl dipli.

She smiled deeply.

mæt stʊd, stʌnd. "æn huz gɑnə blʌɾi mɛɹi ju?" hi blɝɾɪd aʊt. "ɪt ʃʊɹ əz θʌndɝ ɪzən gɑnə bi mi, əl tɛl jə ðæt."

Mat stood, stunned. "And who's going to bloody marry you?" he blurted out. "It sure as thunder isn't going to be me, I'll tell you that."

ðə tu ɡlænst ət hɪm, θɔɹn wɪð ə flæt stɛɹ, mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ə hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl. "aɪ kən si waɪ ðə sintʃæn wʊmən hæd tə hæv ju, mæt," ʃi noʊɾəd. "ju sɝɾənli hæv ə maɪn fəɹ ɹoʊmæns."

The two glanced at him, Thorn with a flat stare, Moiraine with a hint of a smile. "I can see why the Seanchan woman had to have you, Mat," she noted. "You certainly have a mind for romance."

"aɪ dʒʌst . . ." hi pʊld ɔf ɪz hæt, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ɔkwɝdli, lʊkɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ bɪtwin ðɛm. "aɪ dʒʌst - bɝn mi! haʊ dɪɾ aɪ mɪs ðɪs? aɪ wɑz wɪð ðə tu ʌv jə moʊs ðə taɪm jə wɝ təɡɛðɝ! wən dɪd jə bɪkʌm əfɛkʃənət?"

"I just . . ." He pulled off his hat, holding it awkwardly, looking back and forth between them. "I just - burn me! How did I miss this? I was with the two of you most the time you were together! When did you become affectionate?"

"ju wɝnt wɑtʃɪŋ vɛɹi kloʊsli," θɔɹn sɛd. hi tɝn bæk tə mɔɪɹeɪn. "aɪ əsum jəl wɑn mi əz ə wɔɹɾɝ, tu."

"You weren't watching very closely," Thorn said. He turned back to Moiraine. "I assume you'll want me as a Warder, too."

ʃi smaɪld. "maɪ pɹiviəs ɡeɪɾɪn əz bɪn əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd baɪ ənʌðɝ baɪ naʊ, aɪ hoʊp."

She smiled. "My previous Gaidin has been appropriated by another by now, I hope."

"aɪl teɪk ðə dʒɑb," θɔɹn sɛd, "ðoʊ jəl əv tə ɪkspleɪn tə ɪleɪn waɪ hɝ kɔɹt-bɑɹɾ ɪz sʌmwʌnz wɔɹɾɝ." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ju θɪŋk ðeɪ kən meɪk wʌn ə ðoʊz kʌlɝ-tʃeɪnʒɪŋ kloʊks wɪð səm pætʃəz ɑn ɪt?"

"I'll take the job," Thorn said, "though you'll have to explain to Elayne why her court-bard is someone's Warder." He hesitated. "You think they can make one of those color-changing cloaks with some patches on it?"

"wɛl, jə tu hæv ɡɔn blʌɾi ɪnseɪn, aɪ si," mæt sɛd. "θɔɹn, dɪdn jə wʌns tɛl mi wʌns ðət ðə tu moʊs peɪnfəl pleɪsəz fəɹ jə tə bi wɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn ən keɪɛmlɪn? naʊ jəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ hɛdlɔŋ daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd ðət wɪl ɛnd wɪð jə lɪvɪŋ ɪn wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ!"

"Well, you two have gone bloody insane, I see," Mat said. "Thorn, didn't you once tell me once that the two most painful places for you to be were Tar Valon and Caemlyn? Now you're running headlong down the hillside that will end with you living in one or the other!"

θɔɹn ʃɹʌɡd. "taɪmz tʃeɪnʒ."

Thorn shrugged. "Times change."

"aɪ nɛvɝ əv spɛn mʌtʃ ə maɪ taɪm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃæl ɛndʒɔɪ tʃɹævlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. ʃəd wi sɝvaɪv ðə mʌnθs tə kʌm." ʃi lʊkt ət mæt. "ju ʃəd nɑt spɝn ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn soʊ izəli, mæt. ðə blɛsɪŋz ɪt pɹəvaɪdz wɪl bi ʌv ɡɹeɪt jus tə mɛn ɪn ðiz deɪz."

"I never have spent much of my time in Tar Valon," Moiraine said. "I think we shall enjoy traveling together, Thom Merrilin. Should we survive the months to come." She looked at Mat. "You should not spurn the Warder bond so easily, Mat. The blessings it provides will be of great use to men in these days."

mæt pʊld ɪz hæt bæk ɑn. "ðæt meɪ bi tʃɹu, bʌt jəl nɛvɝ si mi blʌɾi tʃɹæp baɪ wʌn. noʊ əfɛns, mɔɪɹeɪn. aɪ laɪk jə wɛl ɪnʌf. bʌt tə bi bɑndəd tə ə wʊmən? ɪzən gɑnə hæpən tə meɪtʃɹim kɔθən."

Mat pulled his hat back on. "That may be true, but you'll never see me bloody trapped by one. No offense, Moiraine. I like you well enough. But to be bonded to a woman? Isn't going to happen to Matrim Cauthon."

"ɪz ðət soʊ?" tɑm æskt, əmjuzd. "dɪdnt wi dətɝmən ðət jəɹ tuɑn wəd bi keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ, ʃəd ʃi dɪsaɪd tə lɝn?"

"Is that so?" Thom asked, amused. "Didn't we determine that your Tuon would be capable of channeling, should she decide to learn?"

mæt fɹoʊz. blʌɾi æʃəz. tɑm wɑz ɹaɪt. bʌt tʃænəlɪŋ wəd meɪk əɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. ʃi wəd nɑt də sətʃ ə θɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi.

Mat froze. Bloody ashes. Thom was right. But channeling would make her marath'damane. She would not do such a thing. He did not have to worry.

dɪd hi?

Did he?

hi mʌst əv meɪɾ ə feɪs ət ðə θɔt, fəɹ tɑm tʃʌkəld ən mɔɪɹeɪn smaɪld əɡɛn. ðə tu ʌv əm sun lɔst ɪntʃɹəst ɪn spɔɹɾɪŋ wɪð mæt, haʊɛvɝ, ən tɝn tə ə sɑf dɪskʌʃən. ðəɾ əfɛkʃən ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz wɑz tʃɹu. ðeɪ dɪd lʌv itʃ ʌðɝ. laɪt! haʊ hæd mæt mɪst ɪt? hi fɛlt laɪk ə mæn u hæd bɹɔɾ ə hɑɡ tə ə hɔɹs ɹeɪs.

He must have made a face at the thought, for Thom chuckled and Moiraine smiled again. The two of them soon lost interest in sporting with Mat, however, and turned to a soft discussion. That affection in their eyes was true. They did love each other. Light! How had Mat missed it? He felt like a man who had brought a hog to a horse race.

hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf skɛɹs, livɪŋ ðə tu ʌv əm əloʊn. hi wɛn tə skaʊt ði ɛɹiə wɛɹ ðɛɹ ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz səpoʊz tə əpɪɹ. ɪt hæd bɛɾɝ. ðeɪ hæd noʊ səplaɪz, ən mæt dɪd nɑt fænsi flæɡɪŋ daʊn ə ʃɪp ən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðə lɔŋ weɪ bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn.

He decided to make himself scarce, leaving the two of them alone. He went to scout the area where their gateway was supposed to appear. It had better. They had no supplies, and Mat did not fancy flagging down a ship and riding the long way back to Caemlyn.

ɪt wɑz ə ʃɔɹt haɪk əkɹɔs ðə mɛdoʊ tə ðə bæŋks ə ði ɑɹɪnɛl. wʌns ðɛɹ, hi meɪɾ ə smɔl kɛɹn fəɹ noʊl, ðən tɪpt ɪz hæt tə ɪɾ ən sæt daʊn tə weɪɾ ən θɪŋk.

It was a short hike across the meadow to the banks of the Arinelle. Once there, he made a small cairn for Noal, then tipped his hat to it and sat down to wait and think.

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz seɪf. mæt hæd sɝvaɪvd, ðoʊ ðət blʌɾi sɑkət θɹɑb laɪk nʌθɪŋ ɛls. hi stɪl wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ɪf ði ɑfɪn ən ɛlfɪn hæd stʃɹɪŋz ɝaʊn ɪm əɹ nɑt, bʌɾ i hæd ɡɔn ɪndə ðɛɹ dɛn ən kʌm aʊɾ ənskeɪðd. moʊsli, ɛniweɪ.

Moiraine was safe. Mat had survived, though that bloody socket throbbed like nothing else. He still was not certain if the Aeifinn and Eelfinn had strings around him or not, but he had gone into their den and come out unscathed. Mostly, anyway.

wʌn aɪ lɔst. wʌt wəd ðət də tə hɪz əbɪləɾi tə faɪt? ðət wɝiɾ ɪm mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ. hi hæd pʊɾ ɑn ə bɹeɪv fɹʌnt, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪɾ i tʃɹɛmbəld. wʌt wəd tuɑn θɪŋk ʌv ə hʌzbən mɪsɪŋ ən aɪ?

One eye lost. What would that do to his ability to fight? That worried him more than anything. He had put on a brave front, but inside he trembled. What would Tuon think of a husband missing an eye?

ə hʌzbən u maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf?

A husband who might not be able to defend himself?

hi pʊld aʊɾ ə naɪf, flɪpɪŋ ɪt. ðɛn, ɑn ə wɪm, hi tɔst ɪt bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ. hi hɝɾ ə sɑf skɹitʃ, ðən tɝn tə si ə ɹæbət slʌmp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, spɪɹd baɪ ði aɪdli θɹoʊn naɪf.

He pulled out a knife, flipping it. Then, on a whim, he tossed it behind him without looking. He heard a soft screech, then turned to see a rabbit slump to the ground, speared by the idly thrown knife.

hi smaɪld, ðən tɝn bæk tə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðɛɹ, hi noʊɾəst sʌmθɪŋ kɑt bɪtwin tu lɑɹdʒ ɹɪvɝ stoʊnz əlɔŋ ðə ʃɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ən oʊvɝtɝn kʊkɪŋ pɑt, wɪð ə kɑpɝ bɑɾəm, bɛɹli juzd, oʊnli dɪŋɡd ɑn ðə saɪdz ə kʌpəl ə taɪmz. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn dʒɹɑp baɪ ə tʃɹævəlɝ wɔkɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝ.

He smiled, then turned back to the river. There, he noticed something caught between two large river stones along the shore. It was an overturned cooking pot, with a copper bottom, barely used, only dinged on the sides a couple of times. It must have been dropped by a traveler walking up the river.

jɛs, hi maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə dʒʌdʒ dɪstəns, ən i maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə si əz wɛl. bʌt lʌk wɝk bɛɾɝ wən jə wɝ nɑt lʊkɪŋ ɛniweɪ.

Yes, he might not be able to judge distance, and he might not be able to see as well. But luck worked better when you were not looking anyway.

hi smaɪld waɪɾɝ, ðən fɛtʃt ðə ɹæbət - hi wəd skɪn ðət fəɹ sʌpɝ - ən plʌk ðə pɑɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ.

He smiled wider, then fetched the rabbit - he would skin that for supper - and plucked the pot out of the river.

mɔɪɹeɪn wəd ɡɛɾ əɹ ti æftɝ ɔl.

Moiraine would get her tea after all.


ɛpəlɔɡ ən æftɝ



EPILOGUE And After

ɡɹeɪndəl hɝidli ɡæðɝd wʌt ʃi niɾəd fɹəm əɹ nu pæləs. fɹəm əɹ dɛsk, ʃi tʊk ə smɔl æŋɡɹil mɛsænə hæd tʃɹeɪɾɪd əɹ ɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ɪt wɑz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə smɔl, kɑɹvd aɪvɝi naɪf; ʃid lɔst əɹ ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ ɪn ælθɹz ətæk.

Graendal hurriedly gathered what she needed from her new palace. From her desk, she took a small angreal Mesaana had traded her in exchange for information. It was in the shape of a small, carved ivory knife; she'd lost her gold ring in al'Thor's attack.

ɡɹeɪndəl tɔst ɪɾ ɪn əɹ pæk, ðən snætʃt ə ʃif ə peɪpɝz fɹəm əɹ bɛd. neɪmz ə kɑntæks, aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz - ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃid mænədʒ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ fɹəm wʌt hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ət nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ.

Graendal tossed it in her pack, then snatched a sheaf of papers from her bed. Names of contacts, eyes-and-ears - everything she'd managed to remember from what had been destroyed at Natrin's Barrow.

weɪvz sɝdʒd əɡɛns ðə ɹɑks aʊtsaɪd. ɪt wɑz stɪl dɑɹk. oʊnli moʊməns hæd pæst sɪns əɹ læs tul hæd feɪl hɝ, eɪbɑɹə sɝvaɪvɪŋ ðə bæɾəlfild. ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə hæv wɝkt!

Waves surged against the rocks outside. It was still dark. Only moments had passed since her last tool had failed her, Aybara surviving the battlefield. That was supposed to have worked!

ʃi wɑz ɪn əɹ ɛləɡən mænɝ haʊs ə fju liɡz fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ. naʊ ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz ɡɔn, ɡɹeɪndəl hæd bɪɡʌn pleɪsɪŋ səm stʃɹɪŋz ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nu, tʃaɪldlaɪk ɛmpɹɛs. ʃiɾ əv tə əbændən ðoʊz skimz naʊ.

She was in her elegant manor house a few leagues from Ebou Dar. Now that Semirhage was gone, Graendal had begun placing some strings around their new, childlike Empress. She'd have to abandon those schemes now.

pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə hæɾ ɪskeɪpt. ʃi fɛl stʌnd. plæn æftɝ pɝfək plæn hæd fɔlən ɪn pleɪs. ən ðən . . . hiɾ ɪskeɪpt. haʊ? ðə pɹɑfəsi ... ɪt hæd sɛd . . .

Perrin Aybara had escaped. She felt stunned. Plan after perfect plan had fallen in place. And then . . . he'd escaped. How? The prophecy ... it had said . . .

ðət ful hæm, ɡɹeɪndəl θɔt, stʌfɪŋ ðə peɪpɝz ɪn əɹ pæk. ən ðəɾ ɪɾiət waɪtkloʊk! ʃi wɑz swɛɾɪŋ. ʃi ʃʊdn bi swɛɾɪŋ.

That fool ham, Graendal thought, stuffing the papers in her pack. And that idiot Whitecloak! She was sweating. She shouldn't be sweating.

ʃi tɔst ə fju tɛɹæŋɡɹil fɹəm əɹ dɛsk ɪndə ðə pæk, ðən ɹaɪfəld əɹ klɑzət fəɹ tʃeɪnʒəz ə kloʊðɪŋ. hi kəd faɪn əɹ ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə wɝld.

She tossed a few ter'angreal from her desk into the pack, then rifled her closet for changes of clothing. He could find her anywhere in the world.

bʌt pɝhæps wʌn ə ðə mɪɹɝ ɹɛlmz ə ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊnz. jɛs. ðɛɹ, hɪz kənɛkʃənz wɝ nɑt -  ʃi tɝnd, ɑɹmz fʊl ə sɪlk, ən fɹoʊz. ə fɪɡjɝ stʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹum tɔl, laɪk ə pɪlɝ dʒɹɛst ɪn blæk ɹoʊbz. aɪləs. smaɪlɪŋ lɪps ðə kʌlɝ ə dɛθ.

But perhaps one of the mirror realms of the Portal Stones. Yes. There, his connections were not -  She turned, arms full of silk, and froze. A figure stood in the room Tall, like a pillar dressed in black robes. Eyeless. Smiling lips the color of death.

ɡɹeɪndəl dʒɹɑp tə hɝ niz, θɹoʊɪŋ əsaɪd ðə kloʊðɪŋ. swɛt ɹæn daʊn əɹ tɛmpəl ɑntu hɝ tʃik.

Graendal dropped to her knees, throwing aside the clothing. Sweat ran down her temple onto her cheek.

"ɡɹeɪndəl," sɛd ðə tɔl mɹdʒɹɑl. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz tɛɹəbəl, laɪk ðə læst wɪspɝz ʌv ə daɪɪŋ mæn.

"Graendal," said the tall Myrddraal. His voice was terrible, like the last whispers of a dying man.

"ju hæv feɪld, ɡɹeɪndəl."

"You have failed, Graendal."

ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən. vɛɹi bæd. "aɪ . . ." ʃi sɛd, lɪkɪŋ əɹ dʒɹaɪ lɪps. haʊ tə twɪs ðɪs tə ə vɪktɝi? "ɪɾ ɪz əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə plæn. ɪts mɪɹli ə - "

Shaidar Haran. Very bad. "I . . ." she said, licking her dry lips. How to twist this to a victory? "It is according to plan. It is merely a - "

"aɪ noʊ jəɹ hɑɹt, ɡɹeɪndəl. aɪ kən teɪs jəɹ tɛɹɝ"

"I know your heart, Graendal. I can taste your terror"

ʃi skwizd əɹ aɪz ʃʌt.

She squeezed her eyes shut.

"mɛsænə hæz fɔlən," ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən wɪspɝd. "θɹi tʃoʊzən, dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ jəɹ ækʃənz. ðə dɪzaɪn bɪlz, ə læɾəs ə feɪljɝ, ə fɹeɪmwɝk ʌv ɪnkɑmpəɾəns."

"Mesaana has fallen," Shaidar Haran whispered. "Three Chosen, destroyed by your actions. The design builds, a lattice of failure, a framework of incompetence."

"aɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð mɛsænəz fɔl!"

"I had nothing to do with Mesaana's fall!"

"nʌθɪŋ? ɡɹeɪndəl, ðə dʒɹimspaɪk wɑz ðɛɹ. ðoʊz u fɔt wɪð mɛsænə sɛd ðət ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə muv, tə dʒɹɔ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ə loʊkeɪʃən wɛɹ ðɛɹ tʃɹæp kəd bi spɹʌŋ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt mɛn tə faɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðeɪ kəd nɑt liv. kəz ə ju."

"Nothing? Graendal, the dreamspike was there. Those who fought with Mesaana said that they tried to move, to draw the Aes Sedai to a location where their trap could be sprung. They were not meant to fight in the White Tower. They could not leave. Because of you."

"ɪsəm - "

"Isam - "

"ə tul ɡɪvən ju. ðə feɪljɝ ɪz jʊɹz, ɡɹeɪndəl."

"A tool given you. The failure is yours, Graendal."

ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps əɡɛn. hɝ ɪntaɪɝ maʊθ hæd ɡɔn dʒɹaɪ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ aʊt. "aɪ hæv ə bɛɾɝ plæn, mɔɹ boʊld. jəl bi ɪmpɹɛst. ælθɹ θɪŋks aɪm dɛd, ən soʊ aɪ kən - "

She licked her lips again. Her entire mouth had gone dry. There had to be a way out. "I have a better plan, more bold. You will be impressed. Al'Thor thinks I am dead, and so I can - "

"noʊ." sətʃ ə kwaɪət vɔɪs, bʌt soʊ hɔɹəbəl. ɡɹeɪndəl faʊnd ʃi kəd nɑt spik. sʌmθɪŋ hæd teɪkən əɹ vɔɪs. "noʊ," ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən kəntɪnjud. "ðɪs ɑpɝtunəɾi hæz bɪn ɡɪvən tə ənʌðɝ. bʌt ɡɹeɪndəl, jə ʃæl nɑt bi fɝɡɑɾən."

"No." Such a quiet voice, but so horrible. Graendal found she could not speak. Something had taken her voice. "No," Shaidar Haran continued. "This opportunity has been given to another. But Graendal, you shall not be forgotten."

ʃi lʊkt ʌp, filɪŋ ə sɝdʒ ə hoʊp. ðoʊz dɛd lɪps wɝ smaɪlɪŋ waɪdli, ðəɾ aɪləs ɡeɪz fɪkst ɑn hɝ. ʃi fɛlt ə hɔɹəbəl sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ.

She looked up, feeling a surge of hope. Those dead lips were smiling widely, that eyeless gaze fixed on her. She felt a horrible sinking feeling.

"noʊ," ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən sɛd, "aɪ ʃæl nɑt fɝɡɛt ju, ən jə ʃæl nɑt fɝɡɛt ðət wɪtʃ kʌmz nɛkst."

"No," Shaidar Haran said, "I shall not forget you, and you shall not forget that which comes next."

ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz waɪd, ðən haʊld əz i ɹitʃt fəɹ hɝ.

She opened her eyes wide, then howled as he reached for her.

ðə skaɪ ɹʌmbəld; ðə ɡɹæs ɝaʊn pɛɹɪn ʃɪvɝd. ðət ɡɹæs wɑz spɑɾəd blæk, dʒʌst əz ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld. ivən ðə wʊlf dʒɹim wɑz daɪɪŋ.

The sky rumbled; the grass around Perrin shivered. That grass was spotted black, just as in the real world. Even the wolf dream was dying.

ði ɛɹ wɑz fʊl ə sɛns ðət dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ. ə faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ. blʌd dʒɹaɪɪŋ. ðə dɛd flɛʃ ʌv ə bist i dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. ɛɡz ɹɑɾɪŋ.

The air was full of scents that did not belong. A fire burning. Blood drying. The dead flesh of a beast he didn't recognize. Eggs rotting.

noʊ, hi θɔt. noʊ ɪɾəl nɑt bi.

No, he thought. No it will not be.

hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz wɪl. ðoʊz sɛns wəd vænɪʃ. ðeɪ dɪd, ɹipleɪst wɪð ðə sɛns ə sʌmɝ.

He gathered his will. Those scents would vanish. They did, replaced with the scents of summer.

ɡɹæs, hɛdʒhɑɡz, biɾəlz, mɔs, maɪs, blu-wɪŋ dʌvz, pɝpəl fɪntʃɪz. ðeɪ əpɪɹd, bɝstɪŋ tə laɪf ɪn ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn hɪm.

Grass, hedgehogs, beetles, moss, mice, blue-winged doves, purple finches. They appeared, bursting to life in a circle around him.

hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. ðə ɹiæləɾi spɹɛd fɹəm ɪm laɪk ə weɪv, blæknəs feɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə plæns.

He gritted his teeth. The reality spread from him like a wave, blackness fading from the plants.

əbʌv hɪm, ðə klaʊdz ənʒəleɪtɪd, ðən pɑɹɾəd. sʌnlaɪt stʃɹim daʊn. ðə θʌndɝ kɑmd.

Above him, the clouds undulated, then parted. Sunlight streamed down. The thunder calmed.

ən hɑpɝ laɪvz, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hi dʌz! aɪ kən smɛl ɪz koʊt, hɪɹ ɪm ləpɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹæs.

And Hopper lives, Perrin thought. He does! I can smell his coat, hear him loping in the grass.

ə wʊlf əpɪɹd bɪfɔɹ hɪm, fɔɹmɪŋ əz ɪf fɹəm mɪst. sɪlvɝi ɡɹeɪ, ɡɹɪzəl fɹəm jɪɹz ə laɪf.

A wolf appeared before him, forming as if from mist. Silvery gray, grizzled from years of life.

pɛɹɪn θɹɪld ɪn ɪz paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz ɹil.

Perrin thrilled in his power. It was real.

ən ðən i sɔ ðə wʊlfs aɪz. laɪfləs.

And then he saw the wolf's eyes. Lifeless.

ðə sɛn tɝn steɪl ən ɹɔŋ.

The scent turned stale and wrong.

pɛɹɪn wɑz swɛɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə stʃɹeɪn ə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd. sʌmθɪŋ wɪðɪn ɪm bɪkeɪm dɪsdʒɔɪntɪd. hi wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɪndə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim tu stʃɹɔŋli; tə tʃɹaɪ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɪs pleɪs æbsəlutli wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənteɪn ə wʊlf ɪn ə bɑks.

Perrin was sweating from the strain of concentrating so hard. Something within him became disjointed. He was coming into the wolf dream too strongly; to try to control this place absolutely was like trying to contain a wolf in a box.

hi kɹaɪɾ aʊt, fɔlɪŋ tə hɪz niz. ðə mɪsti nɑt-hɑpɝ vænɪʃt ɪn ə pʌf ən ðə klaʊdz kɹæʃt bæk ɪndə pleɪs. laɪtnɪŋ ɪksploʊɾəd əbʌv ɪm ən ðə blæk spɑts flʌɾəd ðə ɡɹæs. ðə ɹɔŋ sɛns ɹɪtɝnd.

He cried out, falling to his knees. The misty not-Hopper vanished in a puff and the clouds crashed back into place. Lightning exploded above him and the black spots flooded the grass. The wrong scents returned.

pɛɹɪn nɛlt, swɛt dʒɹɪpɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bɹaʊ, wʌn hæn ɑn ðə pɹɪkli bɹaʊn ən blæk ɡɹæs. tu stɪf.

Perrin knelt, sweat dripping from his brow, one hand on the prickly brown and black grass. Too stiff.

pɛɹɪn θɔɾ ə feɪl ɪn ðɛɹ tɛn bæk ɪn ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ. ʃi wɑz ɪz hoʊm. ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ tə du. ɹænd hæd kʌm, əz pɹɑməst. təmɑɹoʊ, hi wəd feɪs ɛɡwin. θɔɾ ə ðə ɹil wɝld ɡɹaʊndɪd pɛɹɪn, kipɪŋ ɪm fɹəm ɛntɝɪŋ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim tu stʃɹɔŋli.

Perrin thought of Faile in their tent back in the Field of Merrilor. She was his home. There was much to do. Rand had come, as promised. Tomorrow, he would face Egwene. Thought of the real world grounded Perrin, keeping him from entering the wolf dream too strongly.

pɛɹɪn stʊd. hi kəd də mɛni θɪŋz ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ lɪməts. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz lɪməts.

Perrin stood. He could do many things in this place, but there were limits. There were always limits.

sik baʊnləs. hɪl ɪkspleɪn.

Seek Boundless. He will explain.

hɑpɝz læst sɛndɪŋ tə hɪm. wʌɾ ɪt min? hɑpɝ hæd sɛd ðət pɛɹɪn hæd faʊn ði ænsɝ. ən jɛt, baʊnləs wəɾ ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ ænsɝ? ðə sɛndɪŋ hæd bɪn əwɑʃ wɪð peɪn, lɔs, sæɾəsfækʃən ət siɪŋ pɛɹɪn æksɛp ðə wʊlf wɪðɪn hɪm. wʌn faɪnəl ɪmədʒ ʌv ə wʊlf lipɪŋ pɹaʊdli ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs, koʊt ʃaɪnɪŋ, sɛn dɪtɝmənd.

Hopper's last sending to him. What did it mean? Hopper had said that Perrin had found the answer. And yet, Boundless would explain that answer? The sending had been awash with pain, loss, satisfaction at seeing Perrin accept the wolf within him. One final image of a wolf leaping proudly into the darkness, coat shining, scent determined.

pɛɹɪn sɛn hɪmsɛlf tə ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd. baʊnləs wɑz ɔfən ðɛɹ, wɪð ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə pæk. pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən faʊn hɪm: ə juθfəl meɪl wɪð bɹaʊn fɝ ən ə lin bɪld. baʊnləs tizd ɪm sɛndɪŋ ði ɪmədʒ ə pɛɹɪn əz ə bʊl tʃɹæmplɪŋ ə stæɡ. ði ʌðɝz hæd lɛf ðəɾ ɪmədʒ əloʊn, bʌt baʊnləs kəntɪnjud tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ.

Perrin sent himself to the Jehannah Road. Boundless was often there, with the remnants of the pack. Perrin reached out and found him: a youthful male with brown fur and a lean build. Boundless teased him sending the image of Perrin as a bull trampling a stag. The others had left that image alone, but Boundless continued to remember.

baʊnləs, pɛɹɪn sɛnt. hɑpɝ toʊl mi aɪ niɾəd ju.

Boundless, Perrin sent. Hopper told me I needed you.

ðə wʊlf vænɪʃt.

The wolf vanished.

pɛɹɪn stɑɹɾəd, ðən dʒʌmp tə ðə pleɪs ðə wʊlf hæd 'bɪn - ə klɪf tɑp sɛvɹəl liɡz fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd. hi kɑt ðə feɪntəst sɛn ə ðə wʊlfs dɛstəneɪʃən, ən ðən wɛn ðɛɹ. ən oʊpən fild wɪð ə dɪstən bɑɹn, lʊkɪŋ ɹɑɾɪd.

Perrin started, then jumped to the place the wolf had 'been - a cliff top several leagues from the road. He caught the faintest scent of the wolf's destination, and then went there. An open field with a distant barn, looking rotted.

baʊnləs? pɛɹɪn sɛnt. ðə wʊlf kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ə paɪl ə bɹʌʃ nɪɹbaɪ.

Boundless? Perrin sent. The wolf crouched in a pile of brush nearby.

noʊ. noʊ. baʊnləs sɛn fɹaɪɾ ən æŋɡɝ.

No. No. Boundless sent fright and anger.

wʌɾ aɪ du?

What did I do?

ðə wʊlf stʃɹikt əweɪ, livɪŋ ə blɝ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, ən wɛn daʊn ɑn ɔl fɔɹz, bɪkʌmɪŋ ə wʊlf. jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd, wɪn ɹɔɹɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. hi fɔɹst ɪt tə pɑɹt bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ɪnkɹisɪŋ ɪz spid fɝðɝ.

The wolf streaked away, leaving a blur. Perrin growled, and went down on all fours, becoming a wolf. Young Bull followed, wind roaring in his ears. He forced it to part before him, increasing his speed further.

baʊnləs tʃɹaɪd tə vænɪʃ, bʌt jʌŋ bʊl fɑloʊd, əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði oʊʃən. hi hɪt ðə weɪvz, wɔɾɝ fɝm bɪniθ ɪz pɔz, ən kəntɪnjuɾ æftɝ baʊnləs wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ stʃɹaɪd.

Boundless tried to vanish, but Young Bull followed, appearing in the middle of the ocean. He hit the waves, water firm beneath his paws, and continued after Boundless without breaking stride.

baʊnləsəz sɛndɪŋz flæʃt wɪð ɪmədʒəz. fɔɹəsts. sɪɾiz. filz. ən ɪmədʒ ə pɛɹɪn, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɪm, stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ə keɪdʒ.

Boundless's sendings flashed with images. Forests. Cities. Fields. An image of Perrin, looking down at him, standing outside a cage.

pɛɹɪn fɹoʊz, bɪkʌmɪŋ hjumən əɡɛn. hi stʊɾ əpɑn ðə sɝdʒɪŋ weɪvz, ɹaɪzɪŋ sloʊli ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

Perrin froze, becoming human again. He stood upon the surging waves, rising slowly into the air.

wʌt? ðət sɛndɪŋ hæd bɪn ʌv ə jʌŋɡɝ pɛɹɪn. ən mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn wɪð hɪm. haʊ kəd baʊnləs əv . . .

What? That sending had been of a younger Perrin. And Moiraine had been with him. How could Boundless have . . .

ən sʌɾənli, pɛɹɪn nu. baʊnləs wɑz ɔlweɪz faʊn ɪn ɡildən ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

And suddenly, Perrin knew. Boundless was always found in Ghealdan in the wolf dream.

noʊm, hi sɛn tə ðə wʊlf, naʊ dɪstənt.

Noam, he sent to the wolf, now distant.

ðəɹ wɑz ə stɑɹɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz, ən ðən ðə maɪn vænɪʃt. pɛɹɪn muv tə wɛɹ baʊnləs hæd bɪn, ən ðəɹ smɛld ə smɔl vɪlədʒ. ə bɑɹn. ə keɪdʒ.

There was a start of surprise, and then the mind vanished. Perrin moved to where Boundless had been, and there smelled a small village. A barn. A cage.

pɛɹɪn əpɪɹd ðɛɹ. baʊnləs leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪtwin tu haʊsəz, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət pɛɹɪn.

Perrin appeared there. Boundless lay on the ground between two houses, looking up at Perrin.

baʊnləs wɑz ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl fɹəm ði ʌðɝ wʊlvz, fəɹ ɔl ðət pɛɹɪn naʊ səspɛktəd ðə tʃɹuθ.

Boundless was indistinguishable from the other wolves, for all that Perrin now suspected the truth.

ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊlf. hi wɑz ə mæn.

This was not a wolf. He was a man.

"baʊnləs," pɛɹɪn sɛd, nilɪŋ daʊn ɑn wʌn ni tə lʊk ðə wʊlf ɪn ði aɪz. "noʊm. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi?"

"Boundless," Perrin said, kneeling down on one knee to look the wolf in the eyes. "Noam. Do you remember me?"

ʌv kɔɹs. jə ɑɹ jʌŋ bʊl.

Of course. You are Young Bull.

"aɪ min, dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi fɹəm bɪfɔɹ, wən wi mɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld? jə sɛn ən ɪmədʒ ʌv ɪt."

"I mean, do you remember me from before, when we met in the waking world? You sent an image of it."

noʊm oʊpən ɪz dʒɔz, ən ə boʊn əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðɛm. ə lɑɹdʒ fimɝ wɪð səm mit stɪl ɑn ɪt. hi leɪ ɑn ɪz saɪd, tʃuɪŋ ðə boʊn. jə ɑɹ jʌŋ hʌl, hi sɛnt, stʌbɝn.

Noam opened his jaws, and a bone appeared in them. A large femur with some meat still on it. He lay on his side, chewing the bone. You are Young hull, he sent, stubborn.

"du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə keɪdʒ, noʊm?" pɛɹɪn æsk sɔfli, sɛndɪŋ ði ɪmədʒ. ði ɪmədʒ ʌv ə mæn, hɪz fɪlθi kloʊðɪŋ hæf ɹɪpt ɔf, lɑkt ɪn ə meɪkʃɪft wʊɾən sɛl baɪ hɪz fæmli.

"Do you remember the cage, Noam?" Perrin asked softly, sending the image. The image of a man, his filthy clothing half ripped off, locked in a makeshift wooden cell by his family.

noʊm fɹoʊz, ən ɪz ɪmədʒ weɪvɝd moʊməntɛɹəli, bɪkʌmɪŋ ðəɾ ʌv ə mæn. ðə wʊlf ɪmədʒ ɹiɾənd ɪmiɾiətli, ən i ɡɹaʊld ə loʊ, deɪnʒɝəs ɡɹaʊl.

Noam froze, and his image wavered momentarily, becoming that of a man. The wolf image retuned immediately, and he growled a low, dangerous growl.

"aɪ də nɑt bɹɪŋ ʌp bæd taɪmz tə meɪk jə æŋɡɹi, noʊm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ... wɛl, aɪm laɪk ju."

"I do not bring up bad times to make you angry, Noam," Perrin said. "I... Well, I'm like you."

aɪm ə wʊlf.

I am a wolf.

"jɛs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌt nɑɾ ɔlweɪz."

"Yes," Perrin said. "But not always."

ɔlweɪz.

Always.

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd fɝmli. "wʌns jə wɝ laɪk mi. θɪŋkɪŋ ɪt dɪfɹənli dʌzn meɪk ɪt soʊ."

"No," Perrin said firmly. "Once you were like me. Thinking it differently doesn't make it so."

hɪɹ ɪt dʌz, jʌŋ bʊl, noʊm sɛnt. hɪɹ ɪt dʌz.

Here it does, Young Bull, Noam sent. Here it does.

ðət wɑz tʃɹu. waɪ wɑz pɛɹɪn pɹɛsɪŋ ðɪs ɪʃu? hɑpɝ hæd sɛn ɪm hɪɹ, ðoʊ. waɪ ʃəd baʊnləs əv ði ænsɝ? siɪŋ hɪm, noʊɪŋ u hi wɑz, bɹɔt bæk ɔl ə pɛɹɪnz fɪɹz.

That was true. Why was Perrin pressing this issue? Hopper had sent him here, though. Why should Boundless have the answer? Seeing him, knowing who he was, brought back all of Perrin's fears.

hid meɪd pis wɪð hɪmsɛlf, jɛt hɪɹ wɑz ə mæn u hæd lɔs hɪmsɛlf kəmplitli tə ðə wʊlf.

He'd made peace with himself, yet here was a man who had lost himself completely to the wolf.

ðɪs wɑz wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn tɛɹəfaɪɾ ʌv. ðɪs wɑz wʌt hæd dʒɹɪvən ðə wɛdʒ bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə wʊlvz. naʊ ðət hiɾ oʊvɝkʌm ðæt, waɪ wəd hɑpɝ sɛn ɪm hɪɹ? baʊnləs sɛntɪɾ ɪz kənfjuʒən. ðə boʊn vænɪʃt ən baʊnləs sɛɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ɪz pɔz, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət pɛɹɪn.

This was what Perrin had been terrified of. This was what had driven the wedge between him and the wolves. Now that he'd overcome that, why would Hopper send him here? Boundless scented his confusion. The bone vanished and Boundless set his head on his paws, looking up at Perrin.

noʊm - hɪz maɪn ɔlmoʊst ɡɔn - hæd θɔɾ oʊnli ʌv bɹeɪkɪŋ fɹi ən ə kɪlɪŋ; hid bɪn ə deɪnʒɝ tə ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz nʌn ə ðət naʊ. baʊnləs simd ət pis. wən ðeɪd fɹid noʊm, pɛɹɪn hæd wɝid ðət ðə mæn wəd daɪ kwɪkli, bʌɾ i simd əlaɪv ən wɛl. əlaɪv, ət list - pɛɹɪn kʊdn dʒʌdʒ mʌtʃ əbaʊɾ ɪz wɛlnəs fɹəm haʊ ðə mæn lʊkt ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

Noam - his mind almost gone - had thought only of breaking free and of killing; he'd been a danger to everyone around him. There was none of that now. Boundless seemed at peace. When they'd freed Noam, Perrin had worried that the man would die quickly, but he seemed alive and well. Alive, at least - Perrin couldn't judge much about his wellness from how the man looked in the wolf dream.

stɪl, baʊnləsəz maɪnd wɑz fɑɹ bɛɾɝ naʊ. pɛɹɪn fɹaʊn tə hɪmsɛlf. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛd ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ə ðə mæn noʊm ɪn ðə maɪn ə ðə kɹitʃɝ.

Still, Boundless's mind was far better now. Perrin frowned to himself. Moiraine had said there was nothing left of the man Noam in the mind of the creature.

"baʊnləs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ðə wɝld ə mɛn?"

"Boundless," Perrin said. "What do you think of the world of men?"

pɛɹɪn wɑz ɪmiɾiətli hɪt wɪð ə ɹæpəd səksɛʃən ʌv ɪmədʒəz. peɪn. sædnəs. daɪɪŋ kɹɑps. peɪn.

Perrin was immediately hit with a rapid succession of images. Pain. Sadness. Dying crops. Pain.

ə lɑɹdʒ, staʊt mæn, hæf-dʒɹʌŋk, biɾɪŋ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən. peɪn. ə faɪɝ. fɪɹ, sɑɹoʊ. veɪn.

A large, stout man, half-drunk, beating a pretty woman. Pain. A fire. Fear, sorrow. Vain.

pɛɹɪn stʌmbəl bæk. baʊnləs kɛp sɛndɪŋ ði ɪmədʒəz. wʌn æftɝ ənʌðɝ. ə ɡɹeɪv. ə smɔlɝ ɡɹeɪv bɪsaɪɾ ɪt, əz ɪf fəɹ ə tʃaɪld. ðə faɪɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ. ə mæn -  noʊmz bɹʌðɝ, pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm, ðoʊ ðə mæn hæd nɑt sim deɪnʒɝəs ət ðə taɪm -  ɛnɹeɪdʒd.

Perrin stumbled back. Boundless kept sending the images. One after another. A grave. A smaller grave beside it, as if for a child. The fire getting larger. A man -  Noam's brother, Perrin recognized him, though the man had not seemed dangerous at the time -  enraged.

ɪt wɑz ə flʌd, tu mʌtʃ. pɛɹɪn haʊld. ə ləmɛn fəɹ ðə laɪf ðət noʊm hæd lɛd, ə dɝdʒ ə sɑɹoʊ ən peɪn. noʊ wʌndɝ ðɪs mæn pɹəfɝd ðə laɪf ʌv ə wʊlf.

It was a flood, too much. Perrin howled. A lament for the life that Noam had led, a dirge of sorrow and pain. No wonder this man preferred the life of a wolf.

ði ɪmədʒəz stɑpt, ən baʊnləs tɝn ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ. pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡæspɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ.

The images stopped, and Boundless turned his head away. Perrin found himself gasping for breath.

ə ɡɪft, baʊnləs sɛnt.

A gift, Boundless sent.

"baɪ ðə laɪt," pɛɹɪn wɪspɝd. "ðɪs wɑz ə tʃɔɪs, wɑzn ɪt? jə pɪk ðə wʊlf ɪntɛnʃənəli."

"By the Light," Perrin whispered. "This was a choice, wasn't it? You picked the wolf intentionally."

baʊnləs kloʊzd ɪz aɪz.

Boundless closed his eyes.

"aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ɪt wəd teɪk mi, ɪf aɪ wɝn kɛɹfəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I always thought it would take me, if I weren't careful," Perrin said.

ðə wʊlf ɪz pis, baʊnləs sɛnt.

The wolf is peace, Boundless sent.

"jɛs," pɛɹɪn sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ðə wʊlfs hɛd. "aɪ ʌndɝstænd."

"Yes," Perrin said, laying a hand on the wolf's head. "I understand."

ðɪs wɑz ðə bæləns fəɹ baʊnləs. dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə bæləns fəɹ ɛlaɪəs. ən dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd faʊnd. hi ʌndɝstʊd. ðɪs dɪd nɑt min ðət ðə weɪ hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf luz kəntʃɹoʊl wɑz nɑɾ ə deɪnʒɝ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə faɪnəl pis i niɾəd tə ʌndɝstænd. ðə faɪnəl pis ə hɪmsɛlf.

This was the balance for Boundless. Different from the balance for Elyas. And different from what Perrin had found. He understood. This did not mean that the way he let himself lose control was not a danger. But it was the final piece he needed to understand. The final piece of himself.

θæŋk ju, pɛɹɪn sɛnt. ði ɪmədʒ ə jʌŋ bʊl ðə wʊlf ən pɛɹɪn ðə mæn stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd wʌn ənʌðɝ, ətɑp ə hɪl, ðɛɹ sɛns ðə seɪm. hi sɛn ðəɾ ɪmədʒ aʊtwɝd, əz paʊɝfli əz i kʊd. tə baʊnləs, tə ðə wʊlvz nɪɹbaɪ. tə ɛni hu wəd lɪsən.

Thank you, Perrin sent. The image of Young Bull the wolf and Perrin the man standing beside one another, atop a hill, their scents the same. He sent that image outward, as powerfully as he could. To Boundless, to the wolves nearby. To any who would listen.

θæŋk ju.

Thank you.

"doʊvjndi saʊθis tɑvjə sɑɡən," oʊlvɝ sɛd, θɹoʊɪŋ ðə daɪs. ðeɪ ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə kænvəs flɔɹ ə ðə tɛnt. oʊlvɝ smaɪld əz ðeɪ keɪm ʌp. ɔl blæk dɑts, noʊ weɪvi laɪnz əɹ tʃɹaɪæŋɡəlz. ə lʌki ɹoʊl ɪndid.

"Dovie'andi se tovya sagain," Olver said, throwing the dice. They rolled across the canvas floor of the tent. Olver smiled as they came up. All black dots, no wavy lines or triangles. A lucky roll indeed.

oʊlvɝ muvd ɪz pis əlɔŋ ðə klɔθ bɔɹɾ ə ðə sneɪks ændi fɑksəz ɡeɪm ɪz fɑðɝ hæd meɪd fəɹ hɪm. siɪŋ ðət bɔɹd meɪɾ oʊlvɝ hɝɾ ɛvɹi taɪm. ɪt ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə hɪz fɑðɝ. bʌɾ i kɛpt ɪz lɪp stɪf ən dɪd nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn noʊ. wɔɹiɝz dɪd nɑt kɹaɪ. ən bɪsaɪdz, sʌmdeɪ hi wəd faɪn ðət ʃeɪɾoʊ hu hæd kɪld ɪz fɑðɝ. ðən oʊlvɝ wəd ɡɛɾ ɪz vɛnʒəns.

Olver moved his piece along the cloth board of the Snakes an.d Foxes game his father had made for him. Seeing that board made Olver hurt every time. It reminded him of his father. But he kept his lip stiff and did not let anyone know. Warriors did not cry. And besides, someday he would find that Shaido who had killed his father. Then Olver would get his vengeance.

ðət wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ə mæn dɪd, wən i wɑz ə wɔɹiɝ. hi fɪɡjɝd mæt wəd hɛlp, wʌns i wɑz dʌn wɪð ɔl ə ðɪs bɪznəs ət ðə læs bæɾəl. hi wəɾ oʊ oʊlvɝ baɪ ðɛn, ən nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ ɔl ðə taɪm oʊlvɝ hæd spɛn biɪŋ mæts pɝsənəl mɛsənʒɝ. fəɹ ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən i hæd ɡɪvən ɪm əbaʊt ðə sneɪks ən ðə fɑksəz.

That was the sort of thing a man did, when he was a warrior. He figured Mat would help, once he was done with all of this business at the Last Battle. He would owe Olver by then, and not just for all the time Olver had spent being Mat's personal messenger. For the information he had given him about the snakes and the foxes.

tælmɑnz sæɾ ɪn ə tʃɛɹ bɪsaɪɾ oʊlvɝ. ðə stoʊɪk mæn wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ ə bʊk, oʊnli peɪɪŋ maɪld ətɛnʃən tə ðə ɡeɪm. hi wɑz nɑt nɪɹli əz ɡʊd tə pleɪ wɪð əz noʊl əɹ θɔɹn. bʌt ðɛn, tælmɑnz hæd nɑt bɪn sɛn tə pleɪ wɪð oʊlvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz wɑtʃ oʊvɝ hɪm.

Talmanes sat in a chair beside Olver. The stoic man was reading a book, only paying mild attention to the game. He was not nearly as good to play with as Noal or Thorn. But then, Talmanes had not been sent to play with Olver so much as watch over him.

mæt dɪd nɑt wɑn oʊlvɝ tə noʊ ðəɾ i hæd ɡɔn tə ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ, livɪŋ oʊlvɝ bɪhaɪnd.

Mat did not want Olver to know that he had gone to the Tower of Ghenjei, leaving Olver behind.

wɛl, oʊlvɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə ful, ən i nu wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. hi wɑz nɑt mæd, nɑt ɹɪli. noʊl wɑz ə ɡʊd wʌn tə teɪk, ən ɪf mæt kəɾ oʊnli teɪk θɹi, wɛl . . . noʊl kəd faɪt bɛɾɝ ðən oʊlvɝ. soʊ ɪt meɪd sɛns fəɹ ɪm tə ɡoʊ.

Well, Olver was not a fool, and he knew what was going on. He was not mad, not really. Noal was a good one to take, and if Mat could only take three, well . . . Noal could fight better than Olver. So it made sense for him to go.

bʌt nɛks taɪm, oʊlvɝ wəd də ðə tʃuzɪŋ. ən ðən mæt hæd bɛɾɝ bi naɪs, əɹ i wəd bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd.

But next time, Olver would do the choosing. And then Mat had better be nice, or he would be left behind.

"jɔɹ ɹoʊl, tælmɑnz," oʊlvɝ sɛd.

"Your roll, Talmanes," Olver said.

tælmɑnz mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ, ɹitʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ən tɔsɪŋ ðə hændfʊl ə daɪs wɪθaʊt luzɪŋ ɪz pleɪs ɪn ðə bʊk. hi wɑz ən ɔl-ɹaɪt fɛloʊ, ðoʊ ə lɪɾəl stɪf. oʊlvɝ wəd nɑt tʃuz tə hæv ə mæn laɪk ɪm ɑn ə ɡʊd naɪɾ ə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ən hʌntɪŋ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz. əz sun əz oʊlvɝ wɑz oʊld ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ən hʌntɪŋ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz. hi fɪɡjɝɾ i wəd bi ɹɛɾi ɪn ənʌðɝ jɪɹ əɹ soʊ.

Talmanes mumbled something, reaching over and tossing the handful of dice without losing his place in the book. He was an all-right fellow, though a little stiff. Olver would not choose to have a man like him on a good night of drinking and hunting serving girls. As soon as Olver was old enough to go drinking and hunting serving girls. He figured he would be ready in another year or so.

oʊlvɝ muv ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz, ðən pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs fəɹ ɪz nɛks θɹoʊ. hi hæd fɪɡjɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl aʊt. ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɾ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ aʊt ðɛɹ, ən i hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ tə faɪn ðə wʌn u hæd kɪld ɪz pɛɹəns. bʌt ði æɛlfɪn, ðeɪ kəɾ ænsɝ kwɛstʃənz. hi hæd hɝd mæt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. soʊ oʊlvɝ wəd ɡoʊ ɡɛɾ ɪz ænsɝz, ðən tʃɹæk ðə mæn daʊn. izi əz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs. hi dʒʌs hæd tə tʃɹeɪn wɪð ðə bæn bɪfɔɹhænd, soʊ hi kəd faɪt wɛl ɪnʌf tə si dʌn wʌt niɾəd tə bi dʌn.

Olver moved the snakes and foxes, then picked up the dice for his next throw. He had figured it all out. There were a lot of Shaido out there, and he had no idea how to find the one who had killed his parents. But the Aelfinn, they could answer questions. He had heard Mat talking about it. So Olver would go get his answers, then track the man down. Easy as riding a horse. He just had to train with the Band beforehand, so he could fight well enough to see done what needed to be done.

hi θɹu hɪz daɪs. ənʌðɝ fʊl ɹʌn. oʊlvɝ smaɪld, muvɪŋ ɪz pis bæk təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə bɔɹd, hæf lɔst ɪn θɔɾ ən dʒɹimɪŋ ə ðə deɪ wən i wəd faɪnəli ɡɛɾ ɪz ɹivɛnʒ, laɪk wɑz pɹɑpɝ.

He threw his dice. Another full run. Olver smiled, moving his piece back toward the center of the board, half lost in thought and dreaming of the day when he would finally get his revenge, like was proper.

hi muvd ɪz pis əkɹɔs wʌn mɔɹ laɪn, ðən fɹoʊz.

He moved his piece across one more line, then froze.

hɪz pis wɑz ɑn ðə sɛntɝ spɑt.

His piece was on the center spot.

"aɪ wʌn!" hi ɪkskleɪmd.

"I won!" he exclaimed.

tælmɑnz lʊkt ʌp, paɪp loʊɝɪŋ ɪn ɪz lɪps. hi kɑkt ɪz hɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bɔɹd. "bɝn mi," hi mʌɾɝd. "wi mʌst əv kaʊntəd ɹɔŋ, əɹ . . ."

Talmanes looked up, pipe lowering in his lips. He cocked his head, staring at the board. "Burn me," he muttered. "We must have counted wrong, or . . ."

"kaʊntəd ɹɔŋ?"

"Counted wrong?"

"aɪ min . . ." tælmɑnz lʊk stʌnd. "ju kænt wɪn. ðə ɡeɪm kæn bi wʌn. ɪt dʒʌs kænt."

"I mean . . ." Talmanes looked stunned. "You can't win. The game can't be won. It just can't."

ðət wɑz nɑnsɛns. waɪ wəɾ oʊlvɝ paɪeɪ ɪf ɪt kəd nɑt bi wʌn? hi smaɪld, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə bɔɹd. ðə sneɪks ən ðə fɑksəz wɝ wɪðɪn wʌn tɔs ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɪz pis ən meɪkɪŋ ɪm luz. bʌt ðɪs taɪm, hid ɡɑɾən ɔl ðə weɪ tə ði aʊtsaɪd ɹɪŋ ən bæk. hi hæd wʌn.

That was nonsense. Why would Olver piay if it could not be won? He smiled, looking over the board. The snakes and the foxes were within one toss of getting to his piece and making him lose. But this time, he'd gotten all the way to the outside ring and back. He had won.

ɡʊd θɪŋ, tu. hi hæd stɑɹɾəd tə θɪŋk i wəd nɛvɝ mænədʒ ɪt!

Good thing, too. He had started to think he would never manage it!

oʊlvɝ stʊɾ ʌp, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ɪz lɛɡz. tælmɑnz klaɪmd ɔf ɪz tʃɛɹ, skwɑɾɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə ɡeɪm bɔɹɾ ən skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd, smoʊk aɪdli kɝlɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛn ə hɪz paɪp.

Olver stood up, stretching his legs. Talmanes climbed off his chair, squatting down beside the game board and scratching his head, smoke idly curling from the end of his pipe.

"aɪ hoʊp mæt wɪl bi bæk sun," oʊlvɝ sɛd.

"I hope Mat will be back soon," Olver said.

"aɪm ʃʊɹ hɪl bi," tælmɑnz sɛd. "hɪz tæsk fəɹ əɹ mædʒəsti ʃʊdn teɪk mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ." ðət wɑz ðə laɪ ðeɪ hæd toʊld oʊlvɝ - ðət mæt, θɔɹn ən noʊl hæd ɡɔn ɔf ɑn səm sikɹəɾ ɛɹən fəɹ ðə kwin. wɛl, ðət wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ɹizən ðət mæt wəɾ oʊ hɪm. ɑnəsli, mæt kəd bi soʊ pɹɪm səmtaɪmz, æktɪŋ əz ɪf oʊlvɝ kəd nɑt teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪmsɛlf.

"I'm sure he will be," Talmanes said. "His task for Her Majesty shouldn't take much longer." That was the lie they had told Olver - that Mat, Thorn and Noal had gone off on some secret errand for the Queen. Well, that was just another reason that Mat would owe him. Honestly, Mat could be so prim sometimes, acting as if Olver could not take care of himself.

oʊlvɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt, wɛɹ ə stæk ə mæts peɪpɝz sæt weɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɹɪtɝn. ðɛɹ, pikɪŋ fɹəm bɪtwin tu ʌv ðɛm, oʊlvɝ noʊɾəst sʌmθɪŋ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. ə bɪɾ ə ɹɛd, laɪk blʌd. hi ɹitʃt ʌp, slaɪɾɪŋ ə wɔɹn lɛɾɝ fɹəm bɪtwin tu ʌv ðə ʃits. ɪt wɑz sil kloʊzd wɪð ə dɑləp ʌv wæks.

Olver shook his head, strolling over to the side of the tent, where a stack of Mat's papers sat waiting his return. There, peeking from between two of them, Olver noticed something interesting. A bit of red, like blood. He reached up, sliding a worn letter from between two of the sheets. It was sealed closed with a dollop of wax.

oʊlvɝ fɹaʊnd, tɝnɪŋ ðə smɔl lɛɾɝ oʊvɝ. hi hæd sin mæt kæɹiɪŋ ɪɾ əbaʊt. waɪ hæɾ i nɑɾ oʊpən ɪt? ðət wɑz daʊnɹaɪt ɹud. sɛɾəl hæd wɝk hɑɹd tə ɪkspleɪn pɹəpɹaɪəɾi tə oʊlvɝ, ən waɪl moʊst ʌv wʌt ʃi sɛd meɪd noʊ sɛns - hi dʒʌs nɑɾəd ɪz hɛd soʊ ʃi wəd lɛɾ ɪm snʌɡəl ʌp tə hɝ - hi wɑz ʃʊɹ jə wɝ səpoʊz tə oʊpən lɛɾɝz pipəl sɛn ju, ðən ɹɪspɑn kaɪnli.

Olver frowned, turning the small letter over. He had seen Mat carrying it about. Why had he not opened it? That was downright rude. Setalle had worked hard to explain propriety to Olver, and while most of what she said made no sense - he just nodded his head so she would let him snuggle up to her - he was sure you were supposed to open letters people sent you, then respond kindly.

hi tɝn ðə lɛɾɝ oʊvɝ əɡɛn, ðən ʃɹʌɡd ən bɹoʊk ðə sil. oʊlvɝ wɑz mæts pɝsənəl mɛsənʒɝ, ɔl əfɪʃəl ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɪt wɑz noʊ wʌndɝ mæt səmtaɪmz fɝɡɑt θɪŋz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊlvɝz dʒɑb tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm. naʊ ðət ləpɪn wɑz ɡɔn, mæt wəd niɾ ɛkstʃɹə teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ʌv. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɹizənz oʊlvɝ steɪd wɪð ðə bænd. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌt mæt wəd də wɪθaʊt hɪm.

He turned the letter over again, then shrugged and broke the seal. Olver was Mat's personal messenger, all official and everything. It was no wonder Mat sometimes forgot things, but it was Olver's job to take care of him. Now that Lopin was gone, Mat would need extra taking care of. It was one of the reasons Olver stayed with the Band. He was not sure what Mat would do without him.

hi ənfoʊldəd ðə lɛɾɝ ən ɹimuvd ə smɔl, stɪf pis ə peɪpɝ ɪnsaɪd. hi fɹaʊnd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz. hi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ pɹɪɾi ɡʊd wɪð ɹiɾɪŋ, moʊsli kəz ə sɛɾəl, bʌt səm wɝdz ɡeɪv ɪm tʃɹʌbəl. hi skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd. "tælmɑnz," hi sɛd. "ju ʃəd pɹɑbli ɹɛd ðɪs."

He unfolded the letter and removed a small, stiff piece of paper inside. He frowned, trying to make out the words. He was getting pretty good with reading, mostly because of Setalle, but some words gave him trouble. He scratched his head. "Talmanes," he said. "You should probably read this."

"wʌts ðæt?" ðə mæn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə ɡeɪm. "hɪɹ, naʊ! oʊlvɝ, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ? ðət wɑzn tə bi oʊpənd!" ðə mæn ɹoʊz, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ tə snætʃ ðə peɪpɝ fɹəm oʊlvɝz fɪŋɡɝz.

"What's that?" the man looked up from the game. "Here, now! Olver, what are you doing? That wasn't to be opened!" The man rose, striding over to snatch the paper from Olver's fingers.

"bʌt - " oʊlvɝ bɪɡæn.

"But - " Olver began.

"lɔɹd mæt dɪdn oʊpən ɪt," tælmɑnz sɛd. "hi nu ðəɾ ɪt wəd ɡɛɾ əs taɪɾ ʌp ɪn waɪt taʊɝ pɑlətɪks. hi weɪɾəd ɔl ðoʊz wiks! naʊ lʊk wʌt juv dʌn. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf wi kən stʌf ɪt bæk ɪnsaɪd . . ."

"Lord Mat didn't open it," Talmanes said. "He knew that it would get us tied up in White Tower politics. He waited all those weeks! Now look what you've done. I wonder if we can stuff it back inside . . ."

"tælmɑnz," oʊlvɝ sɛɾ ɪnsɪstənli. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt"

"Talmanes," Olver said insistently. "I think it's important"

tælmɑnz hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi sim tɔɹn fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən hɛl ðə lɛɾɝ soʊ ðət ðə laɪt ʃoʊn bɛɾɝ ɑn ɪt. hi ɹɛɾ ɪt kwɪkli, wɪð ði ɛɹ ʌv ə bɔɪ stilɪŋ fud fɹəm ə stʃɹit vɛndɝz kɑɹɾ ən stʌfɪŋ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ i kəd bi dɪskʌvɝd.

Talmanes hesitated. He seemed torn for a moment, then held the letter so that the light shone better on it. He read it quickly, with the air of a boy stealing food from a street vendor's cart and stuffing into his mouth before he could be discovered.

tælmɑnz wɪspɝɾ ə kɝs ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. hi ɹɛd ðə lɛɾɝ əɡɛn, ðən kɝs mɔɹ laʊdli.

Talmanes whispered a curse under his breath. He read the letter again, then cursed more loudly.

hi ɡɹæbd ɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum ən dæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. hi lɛf ðə lɛɾɝ ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

He grabbed his sword from the side of the room and dashed out of the tent. He left the letter on the floor.

oʊlvɝ lʊkt ɪɾ oʊvɝ əɡɛn, saʊndɪŋ aʊt ðə wɝdz i hæd nɑɾ ʌndɝstʊd ðə fɝs taɪm.

Olver looked it over again, sounding out the words he had not understood the first time.

meɪtʃɹim, ɪf jə ɑɹ oʊpənɪŋ ðɪs, ðən aɪm dɛd. aɪ hæd plæn tə ɹɪtɝn ən ɹilis jə ʌv jəɹ oʊθ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl deɪ. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni pətɛnʃəl kɑmpləkeɪʃənz tə maɪ nɛks tæsk, haʊɛvɝ, ən ə lɑɹdʒ tʃæns ðəɾ əl nɑt sɝvaɪv. aɪ niɾəd tə noʊ ðəɾ aɪd lɛf sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪn u kəd si ðɪs wɝk dʌn.

Matrim, If you are opening this, then I am dead. I had planned to return and release you of your oath in a single day. There are many potential complications to my next task, however, and a large chance that I will not survive. I needed to know that I'd left someone behind who could see this work done.

fɔɹtʃənətli, ɪf ðɛɹz wʌn θɪŋ aɪ bɪliv aɪ kən ɹɪlaɪ əpɑn, ɪts jəɹ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. aɪ səspɛk jə læstəɾ ə fju deɪz bɪfɔɹ oʊpənɪŋ ðɪs lɛɾɝ, wɪtʃ ɪz lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi tə hæv ɹɪtɝn ɪf aɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə. ðɛɹfɔɹ, ðɪs tæsk fɔlz əpɑn ju.

Fortunately, if there's one thing I believe I can rely upon, it is your curiosity. I suspect you lasted a few days before opening this letter, which is long enough for me to have returned if I were going to. Therefore, this task falls upon you.

ðəɹ ɪz ə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɪts ɡɑɹɾəd, bæɹəkeɪɾɪd, ən θɔt sɪkjʊɹ. ɪts nɑt.

There is a Waygate in Caemlyn. It is guarded, barricaded, and thought secure. It is not.

ən ɪnɔɹməs fɔɹs ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn muvz θɹu ðə weɪz təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wən ðeɪ lɛft ɪɡzækli, bʌt ðəɹ ʃəd bi taɪm tə stɑp ðɛm. jə mʌst ɹitʃ ðə kwin ən pɝsweɪɾ əɹ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə weɪɡeɪt. ɪt kən bi dʌn; wɔlɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp wɪl nɑt səfaɪs. ɪf jə kænɑt dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt, ðə kwin mʌs bɹɪŋ ɔl ə hɝ fɔɹsɪz tə bɛɹ əpɑn ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə loʊkeɪʃən.

An enormous force of Shadowspawn moves through the Ways toward Caemlyn. I do not know when they left exactly, but there should be time to stop them. You must reach the Queen and persuade her to destroy the Waygate. It can be done; walling it up will not suffice. If you cannot destroy it, the Queen must bring all of her forces to bear upon guarding the location.

ɪf jə feɪl ɪn ðɪs, aɪ fɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn wɪl bi lɔs bɪfɔɹ ðə mʌnθ ɪz aʊt.

If you fail in this, I fear Caemlyn will be lost before the month is out.

sɪnsɪɹli, vɛɹɪn mæθwɪn oʊlvɝ ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn. wʌt wɑz ə weɪɡeɪt? hi θɔɾ i hæd hɝd mæt ən θɔɹn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. hi tʊk ðə lɛɾɝ ən wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt.

Sincerely, Verin Mathwin Olver rubbed his chin. What was a Waygate? He thought he had heard Mat and Thorn talking about them. He took the letter and walked out of the tent.

tælmɑnz stʊd dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛnt, lʊkɪŋ istwɝd. təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn.

Talmanes stood just outside the tent, looking eastward. Toward Caemlyn.

ə ɹɛɾɪʃ heɪz hʌŋ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, ə ɡloʊ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi. wʌn lɑɹdʒɝ ðən hæd bɪn ðəɹ ɑn ʌðɝ naɪts.

A reddish haze hung on the horizon, a glow over the city. One larger than had been there on other nights.

"laɪt pɹəzɝv ʌs," tælmɑnz wɪspɝd. "ɪts bɝnɪŋ. ðə sɪɾi ɪz bɝnɪŋ." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, əz ɪf klɪɹɪŋ ɪt, ðən ɹeɪzd ə kɔl. "tə ɑɹmz! tʃɹɑləks ɪn keɪɛmlɪn! ðə sɪɾi ɪz ət wɔɹ! tə ɑɹmz, mɛn!

"Light preserve us," Talmanes whispered. "It's burning. The city is burning." He shook his head, as if clearing it, then raised a call. "To arms! Trollocs in Caemlyn! The city is at war! To arms, men!

bɝn mi, wɪv tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ən sælvədʒ ðoʊz dʒɹæɡənz! ɪf ðoʊz fɔl ɪɹiɾoʊ ðə ʃædoʊz hænz, wɝ ɔl dɛd mɛn!"

Burn me, we have to get into the city and salvage those dragons! If those fall irito the Shadow's hands, we're all dead men!"

oʊlvɝ loʊɝd ðə lɛɾɝ ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, aɪz waɪd. tʃɹɑləks ɪn keɪɛmlɪn? ɪt wəd bi laɪk ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪn kɛɹhin, oʊnli wɝs.

Olver lowered the letter in his fingers, eyes wide. Trollocs in Caemlyn? It would be like the Shaido in Cairhien, only worse.

hi hɝiɾ ɪndə mæts tɛnt, stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹʌɡ, ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz niz bɪsaɪɾ ɪz slipɪŋ pælət. hi hɝidli pʊld ət ðə stɪtʃ-ɪŋz ɑn ðə saɪd. ðə wʊl stʌft ɪnsaɪd bʌlʒd aʊt θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ. hi ɹitʃt ɪn, fɪʃɪŋ əbaʊt, ən pʊl fɹi ðə lɑɹdʒ naɪf i hæd hɪɾən ðɛɹ.

He hurried into Mat's tent, stumbling over the rug, and threw himself to his knees beside his sleeping pallet. He hurriedly pulled at the stitch-ings on the side. The wool stuffed inside bulged out through the opening. He reached in, fishing about, and pulled free the large knife he had hidden there.

ɪt wɑz ɹæpt ɪn ə lɛðɝ ʃiθ. hi hæd teɪkən ɪt fɹəm wʌn ə ðə bænz kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz, bɝɡɛvɪn, wən i hæd nɑt bɪn lʊkɪŋ.

It was wrapped in a leather sheath. He had taken it from one of the Band's quartermasters, Bergevin, when he had not been looking.

æftɝ kɛɹhin, oʊlvɝ hæd swɔɹn tə hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i wəd nɛvɝ pɹuv hɪmsɛlf ə kaʊɝɾ əɡɛn. hi ɡɹɪp ðə lɑɹdʒ naɪf ɪn tu hænz, nʌkəlz waɪt, ðən dæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt.

After Cairhien, Olver had sworn to himself that he would never prove himself a coward again. He gripped the large knife in two hands, knuckles white, then dashed out of the tent.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə faɪt.

It was time to fight.

bɑɹiɡə stʌmbəld əz i kɹɔl pæs ðə stʌmp ʌv ə fɔlən tʃɹi. blʌd fɹəm ɪz bɹaʊ dʒɹɪpt ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ðə dɑɹk-spɛkəl nɛɾəlz sim tə soʊk ɪɾ ɪn, fiɾɪŋ əpɑn ɪz laɪf. hi ɹeɪzd ə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hæn tə hɪz bɹaʊ. ðə bændɪdʒ wɑz soʊk θɹu.

Barriga stumbled as he crawled past the stump of a fallen tree. Blood from his brow dripped onto the ground, and the dark-speckled nettles seemed to soak it in, feeding upon his life. He raised a trembling hand to his brow. The bandage was soaked through.

noʊ taɪm tə stɑp. noʊ taɪm! hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fiɾ ən heɪstəli skɹæmbəl θɹu ðə bɹaʊn sɔlif. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə blæk spɑts ɑn ðə plæns. ðə blaɪt, hiɾ ɛntɝd ðə blaɪt. bʌt wʌɾ ɛls wɑz i tə du? ðə tʃɹɑləks ɹæmpeɪdʒ tə ðə saʊθ; ðə taʊɝz hæɾ ɔl fɔlən. kændɝ ɪtsɛlf hæd fɔlən.

No time to stop. No time! He forced himself to his feet and hastily scrambled through the brown sawleaf. He tried not to look at the black spots on the plants. The Blight, he'd entered the Blight. But what else was he to do? The Trollocs rampaged to the south; the towers had all fallen. Kandor itself had fallen.

bɑɹiɡə tʃɹɪpt ən fɛl tə ði ɝθ. hi ɡɹoʊnd, ɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ, ɡæspɪŋ. hi wɑz ɪn ə tʃɹɔf bɪtwin tu hɪlz nɔɹθ ə hiθ taʊɝ. hɪz wʌns faɪn kloʊðɪŋ - koʊɾ ən vɛst ə ɹɪtʃ vɛlvət - wɑz ɹæɡəɾ ən steɪnd wɪð blʌd. hi stæŋk ə smoʊk, ən wən i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, hi sɔ ðə tʃɹɑləks.

Barriga tripped and fell to the earth. He groaned, rolling over, gasping. He was in a trough between two hills north of Heeth Tower. His once fine clothing - coat and vest of rich velvet - was ragged and stained with blood. He stank of smoke, and when he closed his eyes, he saw the Trollocs.

wɑʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz kæɹəvæn, slɔɾɝɪŋ ɪz sɝvəns ən soʊlʒɝz.

Washing over his caravan, slaughtering his servants and soldiers.

ðeɪɾ ɔl fɔlən. θʌm, jæŋ . . . boʊθ dɛd. laɪt, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɛd.

They'd all fallen. Thum, Yang . . . both dead. Light, they were all dead.

bɑɹiɡə ʃʌɾɝəd. haʊ hæɾ i kʌm tə ðɪs? hi wɑz dʒʌst ə mɝtʃənt. aɪ ʃʊɾə lɪsən tə ɹɪbɪk, hi θɔt. smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm hiθ taʊɝ bɪhaɪnd. ðət wɑz wɛɹ ɪz kæɹəvæn hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ. haʊ kəd ðɪs bi hæpənɪŋ?

Barriga shuddered. How had he come to this? He was just a merchant. I should have listened to Rebek, he thought. Smoke rose from Heeth Tower behind. That was where his caravan had been going. How could this be happening?

hi niɾəd tə kip muvɪŋ. ist. hid meɪk fəɹ ɝæfəl. ði ʌðɝ bɔɹɾɝlændz wəd kʊdn əv fɔlən, kəd ðeɪ?

He needed to keep moving. East. He'd make for Arafel. The other Borderlands would couldn't have fallen, could they?

hi klaɪmd ʌp ə hɪlsaɪd, hænz pʊlɪŋ əɡɛnst ʃɔɹt, kɔɪlɪŋ tʃoʊk-vaɪn. laɪk wɝmz bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ wuzi. hi ɹitʃt ðə hɪltɑp; ðə wɝld wɑz spɪnɪŋ. hi fɛl ðɛɹ, blʌd sipɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bændɪdʒ.

He climbed up a hillside, hands pulling against short, coiling choke-vine. Like worms between his fingers. He was growing woozy. He reached the hilltop; the world was spinning. He fell there, blood seeping from his bandage.

sʌmθɪŋ muvd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. hi blɪŋkt. ðoʊz klaʊdz əbʌv wɝ ə tɛmpəst. ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, θɹi fɪɡjɝz wɛɹɪŋ blæk ən bɹaʊn əpɹoʊtʃt wɪð ə slik ɡɹeɪs. mɹdʒɹɑl!

Something moved in front of him. He blinked. Those clouds above were a tempest. In front of him, three figures wearing black and brown approached with a sleek grace. Myrddraal!

noʊ. hi blɪŋk ðə tɪɹz ən blʌd fɹəm ɪz aɪz. noʊ, ðoʊz wɝn mɹdʒɹɑl. ðeɪ wɝ mɛn, wɛɹɪŋ ɹɛd veɪlz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ðeɪ wɔkt əɾ ə kɹaʊtʃ, skænɪŋ ðə tɝeɪn, ʃɔɹt spɪɹz wɔɹn ɑn ðɛɹ bæks.

No. He blinked the tears and blood from his eyes. No, those weren't Myrddraal. They were men, wearing red veils over their faces. They walked at a crouch, scanning the terrain, short spears worn on their backs.

"laɪt bi pɹeɪzd," hi wɪspɝd. "il." hid bɪn ɪn ændɝ wən ɹænd ælθɹ hæd kʌm.

"Light be praised," he whispered. "Aiel." He'd been in Andor when Rand al'Thor had come.

ɛvɹiwʌn nu ði il fɑloʊd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi hæd teɪm ðɛm.

Everyone knew the Aiel followed the Dragon Reborn. He had tamed them.

aɪm seɪf!

I'm safe!

wʌn ə ði il stɛpt ʌp tə bɑɹiɡə. waɪ wɑz ðə mænz veɪl ɹɛd? ðət wɑz ənjuʒəwəl. ði ilz dɑɹk aɪz wɝ ɡlæsi ən hɑɹd. ði il mæn əndɪɾ ɪz veɪl, ən ɹɪvild ə smaɪlɪŋ feɪs.

One of the Aiel stepped up to Barriga. Why was the man's veil red? That was unusual. The Aiel's dark eyes were glassy and hard. The Aiel man undid his veil, and revealed a smiling face.

ðə mænz tiθ hæd bɪn faɪl tə pɔɪns. hɪz smaɪl bɹɔɾənd, ən i slɪpt ə naɪf fɹəm ɪz bɛlt.

The man's teeth had been filed to points. His smile broadened, and he slipped a knife from his belt.

bɑɹiɡə stʌɾɝd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðət hɔɹɪfɪk mɔ ən ðə ɡli ɪn ðɪs mænz aɪz əz i ɹitʃt ɪn fəɹ ðə kɪl. ðiz wɝn il. ðeɪ wɝ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls.

Barriga stuttered, looking at that horrific maw and the glee in this man's eyes as he reached in for the kill. These weren't Aiel. They were something else.

sʌmθɪŋ tɛɹəbəl.

Something terrible.

ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, sæt kwaɪətli ɪn ɪz dʒɹim. hi bɹiðd ɪn ðə kul, tʃɪl ɛɹ.

Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, sat quietly in his dream. He breathed in the cool, chill air.

waɪt klaʊdz floʊɾəd dʒɛnli ɝaʊn hɪm, kɪsɪŋ ɪz skɪn wɪð ðɛɹ kɑndənseɪʃən.

White clouds floated gently around him, kissing his skin with their condensation.
