hɪz θɹoʊn fəɹ ðə naɪt wɑz ə flæt boʊldɝ ɑn ə maʊntən sloʊp; hi lʊk daʊn θɹu ðə klaʊdz əɾ ə nɛɹoʊ væli. ðɪs wɑzn ðə ɹil loʊkeɪʃən. ɪt wɑzn ivən ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ðət pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɔt fɔɹseɪkən, ðə pleɪs hid bɪn toʊld wɑz soʊ deɪnʒɝəs.

His throne for the night was a flat boulder on a mountain slope; he looked down through the clouds at a narrow valley. This wasn't the real location. It wasn't even the World of Dreams, that place where he'd fought Forsaken, the place he'd been told was so dangerous.

noʊ, ðɪs wɑz wʌn ə hɪz oʊn ɔɹɾənɛɹi dʒɹimz. hi kəntʃɹoʊld əm naʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ə pleɪs i kəd faɪn pis tə θɪŋk, pɹətɛktəd baɪ wɔɹdz waɪl ɪz bɑɾi slɛp bɪsaɪd mɪn ɪn ðɛɹ nu kæmp, sɝaʊndəd baɪ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, sɛɾ ʌp ɑn ðə fild ə mɛɹɪlɝ. ɛɡwin wɑz ðɛɹ, wɪð ɑɹmiz mɑɹʃəld. hi wɑz ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðæt. hid kaʊntəɾ ɑn ɪt.

No, this was one of his own ordinary dreams. He controlled them now. They were a place he could find peace to think, protected by wards while his body slept beside Min in their new camp, surrounded by Borderlanders, set up on the Field of Merrilor. Egwene was there, with armies marshaled. He was ready for that. He'd counted on it.

ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ, ðeɪd hɪɹ ɪz dɪmænz. nɑt wʌɾ i wəd dɪmæn tə kip ɪm fɹəm bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə silz - hi wɑz gɑnə də ðæt, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ʌv wʌɾ ɛɡwin sɛd.

On the morrow, they'd hear his demands. Not what he would demand to keep him from breaking the seals - he was going to do that, regardless of what Egwene said.

noʊ, ðiz wəd bi ðə dɪmænz i meɪɾ ɑn ðə mɑnɑɹks ə ðə wɝld ɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl tə feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

No, these would be the demands he made on the monarchs of the world in exchange for going to Shayol Ghul to face the Dark One.

hi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt hid də ɪf ðeɪ ɹəfjuz hɪm. ðeɪd faɪn ɪt vɛɹi dɪfəkəl tə də soʊ.

He wasn't certain what he'd do if they refused him. They'd find it very difficult to do so.

səmtaɪmz, ɪt kəd bi jusfəl tə hæv ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ biɪŋ ɪɹæʃənəl.

Sometimes, it could be useful to have a reputation for being irrational.

hi bɹiðd ɪn dipli, pisfəl. hɪɹ, ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz, ðə hɪlz ɡɹu ɡɹin. əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðɛm. ɪn ðət neɪmləs væli bɪloʊ, ʃɛltɝɾ ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, hid bɪɡʌn ə dʒɝni. nɑɾ ɪz fɝst, ən nɑɾ ɪz læst, bʌt pɝhæps ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt. wʌn ə ðə moʊs peɪnfəl, fəɹ sɝɾən.

He breathed in deeply, peaceful. Here, in his dreams, the hills grew green. As he remembered them. In that nameless valley below, sheltered in the Mountains of Mist, he'd begun a journey. Not his first, and not his last, but perhaps the most important. One of the most painful, for certain.

"ænd naʊ aɪ kʌm bæk," hi wɪspɝd. "aɪv tʃeɪnʒd əɡɛn. ə mæn ɪz ɔlweɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ."

"And now I come back," he whispered. "I've changed again. A man is always changing."

hi fɛlt ə junəɾi ɪn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ hɪɹ, tə ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɝs kənfɹʌntəd ðə kɪlɝ ɪnsaɪd hɪm. ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɝs tʃɹaɪd tə fli fɹəm ðoʊz hum i ʃʊɾə kɛp nɪɹ. hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ tʃɹæŋkwɪlɪɾi. kɑmnəs. hɑɹməni.

He felt a unity in returning here, to the place where he'd first confronted the killer inside him. The place where he'd first tried to flee from those whom he should have kept near. He closed his eyes, enjoying tranquility. Calmness. Harmony.

ɪn ðə dɪstəns, hi hɝd skɹimz ə peɪn.

In the distance, he heard screams of pain.

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz aɪz. wʌt hæd ðət bɪn? hi stʊɾ ʌp, spɪnɪŋ. ðɪs pleɪs wɑz kɹieɪɾəd ə hɪz oʊn maɪnd, pɹətɛktəɾ ən seɪf. ɪt kʊdnt -  ðə skɹim keɪm əɡɛn. dɪstənt. hi fɹaʊn ən ɹeɪzd ə hænd. ðə sin ɝaʊn ɪm vænɪʃt, pʌfɪŋ əweɪ ɪndə mɪst. hi stʊɾ ɪn blæknəs.

Rand opened his eyes. What had that been? He stood up, spinning. This place was created of his own mind, protected and safe. It couldn't -  The scream came again. Distant. He frowned and raised a hand. The scene around him vanished, puffing away into mist. He stood in blackness.

ðɛɹ, hi θɔt. hi wɑz ɪn ə lɔŋ kɔɹəɾɝ ə dɑɹk wʊd pænəlɪŋ. hi wɔk daʊn ɪt, buts θʌmpɪŋ. ðət skɹimɪŋ. ɪt ʃʊk ɪz pis. sʌmwʌn wɑz ɪn peɪn. ðeɪ niɾəd hɪm.

There, he thought. He was in a long corridor of dark wood paneling. He walked down it, boots thumping. That screaming. It shook his peace. Someone was in pain. They needed him.

ɹænd bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn. hi ɹitʃt ə dɔɹweɪ ət ði ɛn ə ðə hɔl. ðə dɔɹz ɹʌsət wʊd wɑz nɑbd ən ɹɪdʒd, laɪk ðə θɪk ɹuts ʌv ən eɪntʃən tʃɹi. ɹænd siz ðə hændəl - dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ɹut  - ən ɹɛntʃt ðə dɔɹ oʊpən.

Rand began to run. He reached a doorway at the end of the hall. The door's russet wood was knobbed and ridged, like the thick roots of an ancient tree. Rand seized the handle - just another root  - and wrenched the door open.

ðə væst ɹum bɪɑnd wɑz pjʊɹ blæk, laɪtləs, laɪk ə kævɝn dip bɪniθ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə ɹum sim tə sʌk ɪn ðə laɪɾ ən ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃ ɪt. ðə skɹimɪŋ vɔɪs wɑz ɪnsaɪd. ɪt wɑz wik, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ biɪŋ smʌðɝd baɪ ðə dɑɹknəs.

The vast room beyond was pure black, lightless, like a cavern deep beneath the ground. The room seemed to suck in the light and extinguish it. The screaming voice was inside. It was weak, as if it were being smothered by the darkness.

ɹænd ɛntɝd. ðə dɑɹknəs swɑloʊd hɪm. ɪt sim tə pʊl ðə laɪf aʊɾ ə hɪm, laɪk ə hʌnʒɹəd litʃɪz sʌkɪŋ blʌd fɹəm ɪz veɪnz. hi pɹɛst ɔnwɝd. hi kʊdn dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃ ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə kɹaɪz, soʊ hi muvd əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz; ðeɪ fɛlt laɪk boʊn, smuð bʌɾ əkeɪʒənəli kɹækt.

Rand entered. The darkness swallowed him. It seemed to pull the life out of him, like a hundred leeches sucking blood from his veins. He pressed onward. He couldn't distinguish the direction of the cries, so he moved along the walls; they felt like bone, smooth but occasionally cracked.

ðə ɹum wɑz ɹaʊnd. əz ɪf i stʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə boʊl ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs skʌl.

The room was round. As if he stood inside the bowl of an enormous skull.

ðɛɹ! ə feɪn laɪɾ əhɛd, ə sɪŋɡəl kændəl ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ə flɔɹ ə blæk mɑɹbəl. ɹænd hɝid təwɔɹɾ ɪt. jɛs, ðəɹ wɑz ə fɪɡjɝ ðɛɹ. hʌɾəld əɡɛns ðə boʊn-waɪt wɔl. ɪt wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð sɪlvɝi hɛɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ə θɪn waɪt ʃɪft.

There! A faint light ahead, a single candle on the ground, illuminating a floor of black marble. Rand hurried toward it. Yes, there was a figure there. Huddled against the bone-white wall. It was a woman with silvery hair, wearing a thin white shift.

ʃi wɑz wipɪŋ naʊ, hɝ fɪɡjɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ ən tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. ɹænd nɛl bɪsaɪd hɝ, ðə kændəl flɪkɝɪŋ fɹəm ɪz moʊʃən. haʊ hæd ðɪs wʊmən ɡɑɾən ɪndə hɪz dʒɹim? wɑz ʃi sʌmwʌn ɹil, əɹ wɑz ðɪs ə kɹieɪʃən ə hɪz maɪnd? hi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ.

She was weeping now, her figure shaking and trembling. Rand knelt beside her, the candle flickering from his motion. How had this woman gotten into his dream? Was she someone real, or was this a creation of his mind? He laid a hand on her shoulder.

ʃi ɡlæns təwɔɹd hɪm, aɪz ɹɛd, feɪs ə mæsk ə peɪn, tɪɹz dʒɹɪpɪŋ fɹəm əɹ tʃɪn. "pliz," ʃi plɛd. "pliz. hiz mi."

She glanced toward him, eyes red, face a mask of pain, tears dripping from her chin. "Please," she pled. "Please. He has me."

"hu ɑɹ ju?"

"Who are you?"

"ju noʊ mi," ʃi wɪspɝd, teɪkɪŋ ɪz hænd, klɪŋɪŋ tə ɪt. "aɪm sɑɹi. aɪm soʊ sɑɹi. hiz mi.

"You know me," she whispered, taking his hand, clinging to it. "I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. He has me.

hi fleɪz maɪ soʊl ənu itʃ iv. oʊ, pliz! lɛɾ ɪt stɑp." ðə tɪɹz floʊd mɔɹ fɹili.

He flays my soul anew each eve. Oh, please! Let it stop." The tears flowed more freely.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ju," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ . . ."

"I don't know you," Rand said. "I . . ."

ðoʊz aɪz. ðoʊz bjuɾəfəl, tɛɹəbəl aɪz. ɹænd ɡæspt, ɹilisɪŋ əɹ hænd. ðə feɪs wɑz dɪfɹənt. bʌɾ i dɪd noʊ ðət soʊl. "maɪɹɪn? jəɹ dɛd. aɪ sɔ jə daɪ!"

Those eyes. Those beautiful, terrible eyes. Rand gasped, releasing her hand. The face was different. But he did know that soul. "Mierin? You're dead. I saw you die!"

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ wɝ dɛd. aɪ wɪʃ ɪt. pliz! hi ɡɹaɪnz maɪ boʊnz ən snæps əm laɪk twɪɡz, ðən livz mi tə daɪ bɪfɔɹ hilɪŋ mi dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə kip mi əlaɪv. hi - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf, dʒɝkɪŋ.

She shook her head. "I wish I were dead. I wish it. Please! He grinds my bones and snaps them like twigs, then leaves me to die before Healing me just enough to keep me alive. He - " She cut off, jerking.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

hɝ aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾ ən ʃi spʌn təwɔɹd ðə wɔl. "noʊ!" ʃi skɹimd. "hi kʌmz! ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ɛvɹi mænz maɪnd, ðə mɝɾɝɝ ə tʃɹuθ. noʊ!" ʃi spʌn, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɹænd, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ toʊɾ əɹ bækwɝd. ðə wɔl bɹoʊk əweɪ, ən ʃi tʌmbəld ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

Her eyes opened wide and she spun toward the wall. "No!" she screamed. "He comes! The Shadow in every man's mind, the murderer of truth. No!" She spun, reaching for Rand, but something towed her backward. The wall broke away, and she tumbled into the darkness.

ɹænd dʒʌmp fɔɹwɝd, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ hɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz tu leɪt. hi kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə hɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə blæknəs bɪloʊ.

Rand jumped forward, reaching for her, but he was too late. He caught a glimpse of her before she vanished into the blackness below.

ɹænd fɹoʊz, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðət pɪt. hi sɔt kɑmnəs, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt faɪn ɪt. ɪnstɛd, hi fɛl heɪtʃɹəd, kənsɝn, ən - laɪk ə siθɪŋ vaɪpɝ wɪðɪn ɪm - dɪzaɪɝ. ðət hæd bɪn maɪɹɪn ɝoʊneɪl, ə wʊmən i hæd wʌns kɔl ðə leɪɾi səlin.

Rand froze, staring into that pit. He sought calmness, but he could not find it. Instead, he felt hatred, concern, and - like a seething viper within him - desire. That had been Mierin Eronaile, a woman he had once called the Lady Selene.

ə wʊmən moʊs pipəl nu baɪ ðə neɪm ʃid teɪkən əpɑn hɝsɛlf. lænfɝ.

A woman most people knew by the name she'd taken upon herself. Lanfear.

ə kɹuəl, dʒɹaɪ wɪn blu əkɹɔs lænz feɪs əz i lʊk daʊn əɾ ə kɝʌp lændskeɪp. tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp wɑz ə waɪd pæs, ɹɑki, spɛkəld wɪð blaɪɾɪd naɪfɡɹæs. ðɪs hæd wʌns bɪn pɑɹɾ ə mɔlkiɝ.

A cruel, dry wind blew across Lan's face as he looked down at a corrupt landscape. Tarwin's Gap was a wide pass, rocky, speckled with Blighted knifegrass. This had once been part of Malkier.

hi wɑz hoʊm əɡɛn. fəɹ ðə læs taɪm.

He was home again. For the last time.

mæsəz ə tʃɹɑləks klʌstɝɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡæp. θaʊzənz.

Masses of Trollocs clustered on the other side of the Gap. Thousands.

tɛnz ə θaʊzənz. pɹɑbli hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz. izəli tɛn taɪmz ðə nʌmbɝ ə mɛn læn hæd ɡæðɝd dʊɹɪŋ ɪz mɑɹtʃ əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. nɔɹməli, mɛn hɛld ət ðɛɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡæp, bʌt læn kəd nɑt də ðæt.

Tens of thousands. Probably hundreds of thousands. Easily ten times the number of men Lan had gathered during his march across the Borderlands. Normally, men held at their side of the Gap, but Lan could not do that.

hi hæd kʌm tə ətæk, tə ɹaɪd fəɹ mɔlkiɝ. ændɪɹ ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ɪz lɛft, jʌŋ ksəl ə kændɝ ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt. hi kəd fil sʌmθɪŋ, dɪstənt, ðət hæd ɡɪvən ɪm stʃɹɛŋkθ ɹisənli. ðə bɑn hæd tʃeɪnʒd. ði ɪmoʊʃənz hæd tʃeɪnʒd.

He had come to attack, to ride for Malkier. Andere rode up beside him on his left, young Kaisel of Kandor on his right. He could feel something, distant, that had given him strength recently. The bond had changed. The emotions had changed.

hi kəd stɪl fil nɪneɪiv, soʊ wʌndɝfəl, kɛɹɪŋ, ən pæʃənəɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. hi ʃʊɾə bɪn peɪn tə noʊ ðət naʊ ʃi wəd sʌfɝ wən i daɪd, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ənʌðɝ.

He could still feel Nynaeve, so wonderful, caring, and passionate in the back of his mind. He should have been pained to know that now she would suffer when he died, instead of another.

haʊɛvɝ, ðət kloʊsnɪs tə hɝ - ə faɪnəl kloʊsnɪs - bɹɔɾ ɪm stʃɹɛŋkθ.

However, that closeness to her - a final closeness - brought him strength.

ðə hɑt wɪn sim tu dʒɹaɪ; ɪt smɛld ə dʌst ən dɝt, ən dʒɹu ðə mɔɪstʃɝ fɹəm ɪz aɪz, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪm tə blɪŋk.

The hot wind seemed too dry; it smelled of dust and dirt, and drew the moisture from his eyes, forcing him to blink.

"ɪɾ ɪz fɪɾɪŋ," ksəl sɛd.

"It is fitting," Kaisel said.

"wʌt?" læn æskt.

"What?" Lan asked.

"ðæt wi ʃəd stʃɹaɪk hɪɹ."

"That we should strike here."

"jɛs," læn sɛd.

"Yes," Lan said.

"pɝhæps," ksəl sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪts boʊld. ɪt ʃoʊz ðə ʃædoʊ ðət wɪl nɑt bi biɾən daʊn, ðət wɪl nɑt kaʊɝ. ðɪs ɪz jəɹ lænd, lɔɹd mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən."

"Perhaps," Kaisel said. "But it is bold. It shows the Shadow that we will not be beaten down, that we will not cower. This is your land, Lord Mandragoran."

maɪ lænd, hi θɔt. jɛs, ɪt wɑz. hi nʌdʒ mændɑɹb fɔɹwɝd.

My land, he thought. Yes, it was. He nudged Mandarb forward.

"aɪ æm ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən," læn bɛloʊd. "lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə wɔl ə fɝs faɪɝz, bɛɹɝ ə ðə sɔɹɾ ə ðə θaʊzən leɪks! aɪ wɑz wʌns neɪmd ənælaɪn, bʌɾ aɪ ɹidʒɛk ðət taɪɾəl, fəɹ aɪm əloʊn noʊ mɔɹ. fɪɹ mi, ʃædoʊ! fɪɹ mi ən noʊ. aɪ hæv ɹɪtɝn fəɹ wʌɾ ɪz maɪn. aɪ meɪ bi ə kɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə lænd. bʌɾ aɪm stɪl ə kɪŋɡəl"

"I am al'Lan Mandragoran," Lan bellowed. "Lord of the Seven Towers, Defender of the Wall of First Fires, Bearer of the Sword of the Thousand Lakes! I was once named Aan'allein, but I reject that title, for I am alone no more. Fear me, Shadow! Fear me and know. I have returned for what is mine. I may be a king without a land. But I am still a kingl"

hi ɹɔɹd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd. ə tʃɪɹ ɹoʊz fɹəm bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi sɛn ə faɪnəl, paʊɝfəl sɛnseɪʃən ə lʌv tə nɪneɪiv əz i kɪk mændɑɹb ɪndə ə ɡæləp.

He roared, raising his sword. A cheer rose from behind him. He sent a final, powerful sensation of love to Nynaeve as he kicked Mandarb into a gallop.

hɪz ɑɹmi tʃɑɹdʒ bɪhaɪn hɪm, itʃ mæn maʊntəd - ə tʃɑɹdʒ ə kæn-dɔɹi, ɝæfɛlɪn, ʃaɪnɝənz, ən sɑldəiənz. bʌt moʊst ʌv ɔl mɔlkɪɹi. læn wʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf hid dʒɹɔn ɛvɹi lɪvɪŋ mæn fɹəm ɪz fɔɹmɝ kɪŋdəm u kəd stɪl hoʊld ə wɛpən.

His army charged behind him, each man mounted - a charge of Kan-dori, Arafellin, Shienarans, and Saldaeans. But most of all Malkieri. Lan wouldn't be surprised if he'd drawn every living man from his former kingdom who could still hold a weapon.

ðeɪ ɹoʊd, tʃɪɹɪŋ, bɹændɪʃɪŋ sɔɹdz ən lɛvəlɪŋ lænsɪz. ðɛɹ hʊvz wɝ θʌndɝ, ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz ə kɹæʃ ʌv weɪvz, ðɛɹ pɹaɪd stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðə bleɪzɪŋ sʌn. ðeɪ wɝ twɛlv θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ.

They rode, cheering, brandishing swords and leveling lances. Their hooves were thunder, their voices a crash of waves, their pride stronger than the blazing sun. They were twelve thousand strong.

ən ðeɪ tʃɑɹdʒd ə fɔɹs ʌv ət list wʌn hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti θaʊzənd.

And they charged a force of at least one hundred and fifty thousand.

ðɪs deɪ wɪl bi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn ɑnɝ, læn θɔt, ɡæləpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ðə læs tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn. ðə fɔl ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi.

This day will be remembered in honor, Lan thought, galloping forward. The Last Charge of the Golden Crane. The fall of the Malkieri.

ði ɛn hæd kʌm. ðeɪ wəd miɾ ɪt wɪð sɔɹdz ɹeɪzd.

The end had come. They would meet it with swords raised.

loʊ, ɪt ʃæl kʌm əpɑn ðə wɝl ðət ðə pɹɪzən ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst wʌn ʃæl ɡɹoʊ wik, laɪk ðə lɪmz ə ðoʊz u kɹæftɪɾ ɪt. wʌns əɡɛn, hɪz ɡlɔɹiəs kloʊk ʃæl smʌðɝ ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ʃæl stʃɹɛtʃ fɔɹθ ɪz hæn tə kleɪm wʌɾ ɪz hɪz. ðə ɹɪbɛljəs neɪʃənz ʃæl bi leɪd bæɹən, ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən kɑz tə wip. ðəɹ ʃæl bi nʌn bʌt hɪm, ən ðoʊz u hæv tɝn ðɛɹ aɪz tə hɪz mædʒəsti.

Lo, it shall come upon the world that the prison of the Greatest One shall grow weak, like the limbs of those who crafted it. Once again, His glorious cloak shall smother the Pattern of all things, and the Great Lord shall stretch forth His hand to claim what is His. The rebellious nations shall be laid barren, their children caused to weep. There shall be none but Him, and those who have turned their eyes to His majesty.

ɪn ðət deɪ, wən ðə wʌn-aɪd ful tʃɹævəlz ðə hɔlz ə mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ðə fɝst əmʌŋ vɝmɪn lɪfs ɪz hæn tə bɹɪŋ fɹiɾəm tə hɪm u wɪl dɪstʃɹɔɪ, ðə læs deɪz ə ðə fɔlən blæksmɪθs pɹaɪd ʃæl kʌm. jeɪ, ən ðə bɹoʊkən wʊlf, ðə wʌn hum dɛθ əz noʊn, ʃæl fɔl ən bi kənsum baɪ ðə mɪdnaɪt taʊɝz. ən ɪz dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʃæl bɹɪŋ fɪɹ ən sɑɹoʊ tə ðə hɑɹts ə mɛn, ən ʃæl ʃeɪk ðɛɹ vɛɹi wɪl ɪtsɛlf.

In that day, when the One-Eyed Fool travels the halls of mourning, and the First Among Vermin lifts his hand to bring freedom to Him who will Destroy, the last days of the Fallen Blacksmith's pride shall come. Yea, and the Broken Wolf, the one whom Death has known, shall fall and be consumed by the Midnight Towers. And his destruction shall bring fear and sorrow to the hearts of men, and shall shake their very will itself.

ən ðɛn, ʃæl ðə lɔɹɾ ə ði ivnɪŋ kʌm. ən i ʃæl teɪk əɹ aɪz, fəɹ əɹ soʊlz ʃæl baʊ bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ən i ʃæl teɪk əɹ skɪn, fəɹ əɹ flɛʃ ʃæl sɝv hɪm, ən i ʃæl teɪk əɹ lɪps, fəɹ oʊnli hɪm wɪl wi pɹeɪz. ən ðə lɔɹɾ ə ði ivnɪŋ ʃæl feɪs ðə bɹoʊkən tʃæmpiən, ən ʃæl spɪl ɪz blʌɾ ən bɹɪŋ əs ðə dɑɹknəs soʊ bjuɾəfəl. lɛt ðə skɹimz bɪɡɪn, oʊ fɑloʊɝz ə ðə ʃædoʊ. bɛɡ fəɹ jəɹ dɪstʃɹʌkʃən!

And then, shall the Lord of the Evening come. And He shall take our eyes, for our souls shall bow before Him, and He shall take our skin, for our flesh shall serve Him, and He shall take our lips, for only Him will we praise. And the Lord of the Evening shall face the Broken Champion, and shall spill his blood and bring us the Darkness so beautiful. Let the screams begin, O followers of the Shadow. Beg for your destruction!

 - fɹəm ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə ʃædoʊ ði ɛn ə ðə θɝtinθ bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. ðə toʊmən kæləndɝ (dɪvaɪz baɪ toʊmə dɝ ɑməd) wɑz ədɑptəɾ əpɹɑksəmətli tu sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (æb). soʊ mɛni ɹɛkɝdz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ðəɾ ət ðɛɹ ɛn ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ, pɹəpoʊz baɪ tiəm ʌv ɡɑzɹ, sɛləbɹeɪɾəd fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz ə fɹi jɪɹ (fi).

 - from The Prophecies of the Shadow The End of the Thirteenth Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. The Toman Calendar (devised by Toma dur Ahmid) was adopted approximately two centuries after the death of the last male Aes Sedai, recording years After the Breaking of the World (AB). So many records were destroyed in the Trolloc Wars that at their end there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar, proposed by Tiam of Gazar, celebrated freedom from the Trolloc threat and recorded each year as a Free Year (FY).

ðə ɡɑzɝən kæləndɝ ɡeɪnd waɪɾ æksɛptəns wɪðɪn twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə wɔɹz' ɛnd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ətɛmptəd tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə nu kæləndɝ beɪst ɑn ðə faʊndɪŋ ə hɪz ɛmpaɪɝ (, fɹəm ðə faʊndɪŋ), bʌɾ oʊnli hɪstɔɹiənz naʊ ɹəfɝ tə ɪt. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ wɑz dɪvaɪz baɪ ɝɛn dɪn dʒubaɪ sɔɹɪŋ ɡʌl, ə skɑlɝ ə ðə si foʊk, ən pɹɑməlɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ fɛɹiɾ ə tæɹɑbən. ðə fɛɹid kæləndɝ, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz ə ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The Gazaran Calendar gained wide acceptance within twenty years after the Wars' end. Artur Hawkwing attempted to establish a new calendar based on the founding of his empire (FF, From the Founding), but only historians now refer to it. After the death and destruction of the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar was devised by Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, a scholar of the Sea Folk, and promulgated by the Panarch Farede of Tarabon. The Farede Calendar, dating from the arbitrarily decided end of the War of the Hundred Years and recording years of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

æɛlfɪn: ə ɹeɪs ə biɪŋz, lɑɹdʒli hjumən ɪn əpɪɹəns bʌt wɪð sneɪklaɪk kɛɹəktɝɪstɪks, hu wɪl ɡɪv tʃɹu ænsɝz tə θɹi kwɛstʃənz. wʌtɛvɝ ðə kwɛstʃən, ðɛɹ ænsɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz kɝɛkt, ɪf fɹikwənli ɡɪvən ɪn fɔɹmz ðəɾ ɑɹ nɑt klɪɹ, bʌt kwɛstʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ kən bi ɪkstʃɹimli deɪnʒɝəs. ðɛɹ tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌt ðeɪ kən bi vɪzəɾəd baɪ pæsɪŋ θɹu ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wʌns ə pəzɛʃən ə min bʌɾ ɪn ɹisən jɪɹz hɛld ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. ðeɪ kən ɔlsoʊ bi ɹitʃt baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. ðeɪ spik ði oʊl tʌŋ, mɛnʃən tʃɹiɾiz ən əɡɹiməns, ən æsk ɪf ðoʊz ɛntɝɪŋ kæɹi aɪɝn, ɪnstʃɹəməns ə mjuzɪk, əɹ dɪvaɪsəz ðət kən meɪk faɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ ɛlfɪn, sneɪks ən fɑksəz.

Aelfinn: A race of beings, largely human in appearance but with snakelike characteristics, who will give true answers to three questions. Whatever the question, their answers are always correct, if frequently given in forms that are not clear, but questions concerning the Shadow can be extremely dangerous. Their true location is unknown, but they can be visited by passing through a ter'angreal, once a possession of Mayene but in recent years held in the Stone of Tear. They can also be reached by entering the Tower of Ghenjei. They speak the Old Tongue, mention treaties and agreements, and ask if those entering carry iron, instruments of music, or devices that can make fire. See also Eelfinn, Snakes and Foxes.

ɑɹæd dumən: ə neɪʃən ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, kɝənli ɹæk baɪ sɪvəl wɔɹ ən baɪ wɔɹz əɡɛns ðoʊz u hæv dɪklɛɹd fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪts kæpəɾəl ɪz bændɑɹ ɛbən, wɛɹ mɛni ʌv ɪts pipəl əv kʌm fəɹ ɹɛfjudʒ. fuɾ ɪz skɛɹs. ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðoʊz u ɑɹ dɪsɛndəd fɹəm ðə noʊbɪləɾi ət ðə taɪm ə ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə neɪʃən, əz əpoʊz tə ðoʊz ɹeɪz leɪɾɝ, ɑɹ noʊn əz ðə blʌdbɔɹn.

Arad Doman: A nation on the Aryth Ocean, currently racked by civil war and by wars against those who have declared for the Dragon Reborn. Its capital is Bandar Eban, where many of its people have come for refuge. Food is scarce. In Arad Doman, those who are descended from the nobility at the time of the founding of the nation, as opposed to those raised later, are known as the bloodborn.

ðə ɹulɝ (kɪŋ əɹ kwin) ɪz ɪlɛktəd baɪ ə kaʊnsəl ə ðə hɛdz ə mɝtʃənt ɡɪlz (ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns), hu ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz wɪmən. hi əɹ ʃi mʌs bi fɹəm ðə noʊbəl klæs, nɑt ðə mɝtʃənt, ən ɪz ɪlɛktəd fəɹ laɪf. liɡəli ðə kɪŋ əɹ kwin əz æbsəluɾ əθɔɹəɾi, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i əɹ ʃi kən bi dɪpoʊz baɪ ə θɹi-kɔɹɾɝ voʊɾ ə ðə kaʊnsəl. ðə kɝən ɹulɝ ɪz kɪŋ ælsələm sɑiɾ ælməɾɝ, lɔɹɾ ʌv ælməɾɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs ælməɾɝ.

The ruler (king or queen) is elected by a council of the heads of merchant guilds (the Council of Merchants), who are almost always women. He or she must be from the noble class, not the merchant, and is elected for life. Legally the king or queen has absolute authority, except that he or she can be deposed by a three-quarter vote of the Council. The current ruler is King Alsalam Saeed Almadar, Lord of Almadar, High Seat of House Almadar.

ɛɹiə, junəts ʌv: (wʌn) lænd: wʌn ɹɪbən ikwəlz twɛnti peɪsɪz ɛks tɛn peɪsɪz (tuhʌnʒɹəd skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn kɔɹɾ ikwəlz twɛnti peɪsɪz ɛks fɪfti peɪsɪz (wʌnθaʊzən skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn haɪɾ ikwəlz wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ɛks wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz (tɛnθaʊzən skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn ɹoʊp ikwəlz wʌnhʌnʒɹəd

area, units of: (1) Land: 1 ribbon = 20 paces X 10 paces (200 square paces); 1 cord = 20 paces X 50 paces (1000 square paces); 1 hide = 100 paces X 100 paces (10,000 square paces); 1 rope = 100

peɪsɪz ɛks wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz (wʌnhʌnʒɹədθaʊzənd skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); fɝs mɑɹtʃ ikwəlz wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz ɛks wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz (wʌnfɔɹθ skwɛɹ maɪl).

paces X 1000 paces (100,000 square paces); 1 march = 1000 paces X 1000 paces (1/4 square mile).

(tu) klɔθ: wʌn peɪs ikwəlz wʌn peɪs plʌs wʌn hæn ɛks wʌn peɪs plʌs wʌn hænd.

(2) Cloth: 1 pace = 1 pace plus 1 hand X 1 pace plus 1 hand.

æʃəmən: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ɡɑɹɾiən" əɹ "ɡɑɹɾiənz," bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ə ɡɑɹɾiən ə dʒʌstəs ən tʃɹuθ. (tu) ðə neɪm ɡɪvən, boʊθ kəlɛktɪvli ən əz ə ɹæŋk, tə ðə mɛn u hæv kʌm tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ændɝ, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə lɝn tə tʃænəl. ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ lɑɹdʒli kɑnsəntʃɹeɪts ɑn ðə weɪz ɪn wɪtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən bi juzd əz ə wɛpən, ən ɪn ənʌðɝ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ fɹəm ðə jusədʒəz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wʌns ðeɪ lɝn tə siz seɪɾɪn, ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd tə pɝfɔɹm ɔl tʃɔɹz ən leɪbɝz wɪð ðə paʊɝ. wən nuli ɛnɹoʊld, ə mæn ɪz tɝmd ə soʊlʒɝ; hi wɛɹz ə pleɪn blæk koʊt wɪð ə haɪ kɑlɝ, ɪn ði ændɔɝən fæʃən. biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə dɛɾəkeɪtəd bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ pɪn, kɔl ðə sɔɹd, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz koʊt. pɹəmoʊʃən tə æʃəmən bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə dʒɹæɡən pɪn, ɪn ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ɪnæməl, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ɑpəzət ðə sɔɹd.

Asha'man: (1) In the Old Tongue, "Guardian" or "Guardians," but always a guardian of justice and truth. (2) The name given, both collectively and as a rank, to the men who have come to the Black Tower, near Caemlyn in Andor, in order to learn to channel. Their training largely concentrates on the ways in which the One Power can be used as a weapon, and in another departure from the usages of the White Tower, once they learn to seize saidin, the male half of the Power, they are required to perform all chores and labors with the Power. When newly enrolled, a man is termed a soldier; he wears a plain black coat with a high collar, in the Andoran fashion. Being raised to Dedicated brings the right to wear a silver pin, called the Sword, on the collar of his coat. Promotion to Asha'man brings the right to wear a Dragon pin, in gold and red enamel, on the collar opposite the Sword.

ɔlðoʊ mɛni wɪmən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ waɪvz, fli wən ðeɪ lɝn ðət ðɛɹ mɛn æktʃəli  kən tʃænəl, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə mɛn ət ðə blæk taʊɝ ɑɹ mɛɹid, ən ðeɪ juz ə vɝʒən ə ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn tə kɹieɪɾ ə lɪŋk wɪð ðɛɹ waɪvz. ðɪs seɪm bɑnd, ɔltɝd tə kəmpɛl oʊbiɾiəns, hæz bɪn juz tə bɑn kæptʃɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz wɛl. səm æʃəmən əv bɪn bɑndəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔlðoʊ ðə tʃɹədɪʃənəl wɔɹɾɝ bɑn ɪz juzd.

Although many women, including wives, flee when they learn that their men actually can channel, a fair number of men at the Black Tower are married, and they use a version of the Warder bond to create a link with their wives. This same bond, altered to compel obedience, has been used to bond captured Aes Sedai as well. Some Asha'man have been bonded by Aes Sedai, although the traditional Warder bond is used.

ði æʃəmən ɑɹ lɛd baɪ mæzɹim teɪm, hu hæz staɪl hɪmsɛlf ðə l, oʊl tʌŋ fəɹ "liɾɝ."

The Asha'man are led by Mazrim Taim, who has styled himself the M'Hael, Old Tongue for "leader."

ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf." ɪts loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ɹɪɾiən.

Avendesora: In the Old Tongue, "the Tree of Life." It is located in Rhuidean.

beɪlwɝ, sɛbæn: fɔɹmɝli peɪdʒɹən naɪlz sɛkɹətɛɹi, ɪn pʌblɪk, ən sikɹɪtli naɪlz spaɪ mæstɝ. hi eɪɾəd mɔɹɡeɪsəz ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə sintʃæn ɪn æmədɔɹ fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz, ən naʊ ɪz ɛmplɔɪɾ əz sɛkɹətɛɹi tə pɛɹɪn tæʃɪɹ eɪbɑɹə ən feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. hɪz duɾiz ɪkspændəd, haʊɛvɝ, ən i naʊ dɝɛks tʃɑ feɪl ɪn ðɛɹ æktɪvəɾiz, æktɪŋ əz ə spaɪmæstɝ fəɹ pɛɹɪn, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn dʌzn θɪŋk ə hɪm soʊ. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɑ feɪl.

Balwer, Sebban: Formerly Pedron Niall's secretary, in public, and secretly Niall's spy master. He aided Morgase's escape from the Seanchan in Amador for his own reasons, and now is employed as secretary to Perrin t'Bashere Aybara and Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara. His duties expanded, however, and he now directs Cha Faile in their activities, acting as a spymaster for Perrin, though Perrin doesn't think of him so. See also Cha Faile.

bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd: si ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ.

Band of the Red Hand: See Shen an Calhar.

blʌdnaɪvz: ən ɪlit dɪvɪʒən ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz. itʃ ɪz ɪkwɪpt wɪð ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðəɾ ɪnkɹisəz ðɛɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ən spidz ən ʃɹaʊdz ɪm ɪn dɑɹknəs. ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪz æktəveɪɾəd baɪ tʌtʃɪŋ ə dʒɹɑp ə ðə blʌdnaɪfs blʌd tə ðə ɹɪŋ, ən wʌns æktəveɪɾəd, ɪt sloʊli litʃɪz ðə laɪf fɹəm ɪts hoʊst. dɛθ əkɝz wɪðɪn ə mæɾɝ ə deɪz.

Bloodknives: An elite division of Seanchan soldiers. Each is equipped with a ter'angreal that increases their strength and speeds and shrouds him in darkness. The ter'angreal is activated by touching a drop of the Bloodknife's blood to the ring, and once activated, it slowly leaches the life from its host. Death occurs within a matter of days.

bɹaʊn ədʒɑ kaʊnsəl: ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ ɪz hɛɾəd baɪ ə kaʊnsəl ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Brown Ajah Council: The Brown Ajah is headed by a council instead of an individual Aes Sedai.

ðə kɝən hɛɾ ə ðə kaʊnsəl ɪz dʒɛsi biləl; ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ɑɹ ənnoʊn.

The current head of the council is Jesse Bilal; the other members are unknown.

kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl: (wʌn) ðə mɪlətɛɹi ɹæŋk ə ðə liɾɝ ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑ-hilaɪən. (tu) ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ ædlɔɹnə bæstin.

Captain-General: (1) The military rank of the leader of the Queen's Guard of Andor. This position is currently held by Lady Birgitte Tra-helion. (2) The title given to the head of the Green Ajah. This position is currently held by Adelorna Bastine.

kæləndɝ: ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn deɪz tə ðə wik, twɛntieɪt deɪz tə ðə mʌnθ ən θɝtin mʌnθs tə ðə jɪɹ. sɛvɹəl fis deɪz ɑɹ nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni mʌnθ; ðiz ɪnklud sʌndeɪ (ðə lɔŋɡəs deɪ ʌv ðə jɪɹ), ðə fist ə θæŋksɡɪvɪŋ (wʌns ɛvɹi fɔɹ jɪɹz ət ðə spɹɪŋ ikwənɑks) ən ðə fist ʌv ɔl soʊlz sælveɪʃən, ɔlsoʊ kɔld ɔl soʊlz deɪ (wʌns ɛvɹi tɛn jɪɹz ət ði ɔɾəm ikwənɑks). waɪl ðə mʌnθs əv neɪmz (teɪʃəm, dʒumɑɹə, seɪbən, eɪn, ədɑɹ, sævən, ɑmɑdeɪn, tæməz, meɪaɪɡdəl, kɔɹən, ʃɔldin, nɛzæn ən dænu), ðiz ɑɹ sɛldəm juzd ɪksɛpt ɪn əfɪʃəl dɑkjəməns ən baɪ əfɪʃəlz. fəɹ moʊs pipəl, juzɪŋ ðə sizənz ɪz ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf.

calendar: There are 10 days to the week, 28 days to the month and 13 months to the year. Several feast days are not part of any month; these include Sunday (the longest day of the year), the Feast of Thanksgiving (once every four years at the spring equinox) and the Feast of All Souls Salvation, also called All Souls Day (once every ten years at the autumn equinox). While the months have names (Taisham, Jumara, Saban, Aine, Adar, Saven, Amadaine, Tammaz, Maigdhal, Choren, Shaldine, Nesan and Danu), these are seldom used except in official documents and by officials. For most people, using the seasons is good enough.

kælændɝ: ðə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd, ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt. ə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd wʌns hɛld ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, ɪts ə paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil fəɹ jus baɪ meɪl tʃænlɝz. ɪts noʊn flɔz: ɪt læks ðə bʌfɝ ðət meɪks sɑŋɡɹil seɪf tə juz, ən mæɡnəfaɪd ðə teɪnt. ʌðɝ flɔz ɑɹ səspɛktəd.

Callandor: The Sword That Is Not a Sword, the Sword That Cannot Be Touched. A crystal sword once held in the Stone of Tear, it is a powerful sa'angreal for use by male channelers. It has known flaws: It lacks the buffer that makes sa'angreal safe to use, and magnified the taint. Other flaws are suspected.

tʃɑ feɪl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə fælkənz tælən." (tu) neɪm teɪkən baɪ ðə jʌŋ kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹənz, ətɛmptəd fɑloʊɝz ə dʒiɾoʊ, hu hæv swɔɹn fiəlti tə feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. ɪn sikɹət, ðeɪ ækt əz əɹ pɝsənəl skaʊts ən spaɪz. dʊɹɪŋ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðeɪ kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ æktɪvəɾiz ʌndɝ ðə ɡaɪɾəns ə sɛbæn beɪlwɝ. si ɔlsoʊ beɪlwɝ, sɛbæn.

Cha Faile: (1) In the Old Tongue, "the Falcon's Talon." (2) Name taken by the young Cairhienin and Tairens, attempted followers of ji'e'toh, who have sworn fealty to Faile ni Bashere tAybara. In secret, they act as her personal scouts and spies. During her captivity with the Shaido, they continued their activities under the guidance of Sebban Balwer. See also Balwer, Sebban.

tʃɛɝɪn, dʒaɪn: si fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, dʒaɪn.

Charin, Jain: See Farstrider, Jain.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: səsaɪəɾi ʌv stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, oʊɪŋ əlidʒəns tə noʊ neɪʃən ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz baɪ lɑthɛɹ mæntəlɝ tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛnst ən ɪnkɹis ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi səsaɪəɾi. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bɪlifs, ən sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əm tə bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz. noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks, ə neɪm ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz dɪspaɪz, ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹmɝli hɛdkɔɹɾɝd ɪn æmədɔɹ, ɑmɑdɪʃiə, bʌt wɝ fɔɹst aʊt wən ðə sintʃæn kɑŋkɝd ðə sɪɾi. ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd bɪkeɪm lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ æftɝ i kɪld imən vɑldə ɪn ə duəl fəɹ əsɔltɪŋ ɪz stɛpmʌðɝ, mɔɹɡeɪs. vɑldəz dɛθ pɹədust ə skɪzəm ɪn ði ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, wɪð ɡɑləd liɾɪŋ wʌn fækʃən, ən ɹɑɾəm əsunɑwə, haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, liɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt. si ɔlsoʊ kwɛstʃənɝz.

Children of the Light: Society of strict ascetic beliefs, owing allegiance to no nation and dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years by Lothair Mantelar to proselytize against an increase in Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military society. They are extremely rigid in their beliefs, and certain that only they know the truth and the right. They consider Aes Sedai and any who support them to be Darkfriends. Known disparagingly as Whitecloaks, a name they themselves despise, they were formerly headquartered in Amador, Amadicia, but were forced out when the Seanchan conquered the city. Galad Damodred became Lord Captain Commander after he killed Eamon Valda in a duel for assaulting his stepmother, Morgase. Valda's death produced a schism in the organization, with Galad leading one faction, and Rhadam Asunawa, High Inquisitor of the Hand of the Light, leading the other. Their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white. See also Questioners.

kənsɑlədeɪʃən, ðə: wən ði ɑɹmiz sɛn baɪ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz sʌn luthɛɹ lændəɾ ɪn sintʃæn, ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝɾ ə ʃɪftɪŋ kwɪlt ə neɪʃənz ɔfən ət wɔɹ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ, wɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔfən ɹeɪnd. wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɪkwɪvələn ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ɪntʃɹəst, juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. fɔɹmɪŋ smɔl ɡɹups, ðeɪ skimd əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ kɑnstənli. ɪn lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz ðɪs kɑnstən skimɪŋ fəɹ pɝsənəl ædvæntɪdʒ ən ðə ɹɪzʌltɪŋ wɔɹz əmʌŋ ðə mɪɹiəd neɪʃənz ðəɾ əlaʊd ði ɑɹmiz fɹəm ist ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə bɪɡɪn ðə kɑŋkwɛst ʌv ən ɪntaɪɝ kɑntənənt, ən fəɹ ðɛɹ dɪsɛndəns tə kəmpliɾ ɪt. ðɪs kɑŋkwɛst, dʊɹɪŋ wɪtʃ ðə dɪsɛndəns ə ði ɝɪdʒənəl ɑɹmiz bɪkeɪm sintʃæn əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ kɑŋkɝd sintʃæn, tʊk sɛntʃɝiz ən ɪz kɔl ðə kənsɑlədeɪʃən. si ɔlsoʊ taʊɝz ə mɪdnaɪt.

Consolidation, the: When the armies sent by Artur Hawkwing under his son Luthair landed in Seanchan, they discovered a shifting quilt of nations often at war with one another, where Aes Sedai often reigned. Without any equivalent of the White Tower, Aes Sedai worked for their own individual interest, using the Power. Forming small groups, they schemed against one another constantly. In large part it was this constant scheming for personal advantage and the resulting wars among the myriad nations that allowed the armies from east of the Aryth Ocean to begin the conquest of an entire continent, and for their descendants to complete it. This conquest, during which the descendants of the original armies became Seanchan as much as they conquered Seanchan, took centuries and is called the Consolidation. See also Towers of Midnight.

kwəndɪlɝ: ə səpoʊzədli ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl sʌbstəns kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɛni noʊn fɔɹs juzd ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ɪt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɪz əbzɔɹbd, meɪkɪŋ kwəndɪlɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ. ɔlðoʊ ðə meɪkɪŋ ə kwəndɪlɝ wɑz θɔt lɔs fɝɛvɝ, nu ɑbʒɛkts meɪd fɹəm ɪɾ əv sɝfɪst. ɪts ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz hɑɹtstoʊn.

cuendillar: A supposedly indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. Any known force used in an attempt to break it, including the One Power, is absorbed, making cuendillar stronger. Although the making of cuendillar was thought lost forever, new objects made from it have surfaced. It is also known as heartstone.

kɝənsi: æftɝ mɛni sɛntʃɝiz ə tʃɹeɪd, ðə stændɝd tɝmz fəɹ kɔɪnz ɑɹ ðə seɪm ɪn ɛvɹi lænd:

currency: After many centuries of trade, the standard terms for coins are the same in every land:

kɹaʊnz (ðə lɑɹdʒəs kɔɪn ɪn saɪz), mɑɹks ən pɛniz. kɹaʊnz ən mɑɹks kən bi mɪntɪɾ ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, waɪl pɛniz kən bi sɪlvɝ əɹ kɑpɝ, ðə læst ɔfən kɔl sɪmpli ə kɑpɝ. ɪn dɪfɹən lænz, haʊɛvɝ, ðiz kɔɪnz ɑɹ ə dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən weɪts. ivən ɪn wʌn neɪʃən, kɔɪnz ə dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən weɪts əv bɪn mɪntɪd baɪ dɪfɹən ɹulɝz. kəz ə tʃɹeɪd, ðə kɔɪnz ə mɛni neɪʃənz kən bi faʊn ɔlmoʊst ɛniwɛɹ, ən fəɹ ðət ɹizən, bæŋkɝz, mʌnilɛndɝz ən mɝtʃəns ɔl jus skeɪlz tə dətɝmən ðə vælju ʌv ɛni ɡɪvən kɔɪn. ivən lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə kɔɪnz ɑɹ weɪd.

crowns (the largest coin in size), marks and pennies. Crowns and marks can be minted of gold or silver, while pennies can be silver or copper, the last often called simply a copper. In different lands, however, these coins are of different sizes and weights. Even in one nation, coins of different sizes and weights have been minted by different rulers. Because of trade, the coins of many nations can be found almost anywhere, and for that reason, bankers, moneylenders and merchants all use scales to determine the value of any given coin. Even large numbers of coins are weighed.

ðə hɛviəs kɔɪnz kʌm fɹəm ændɝ ən tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɪn ðoʊz tu pleɪsəz ðə ɹɛləɾɪv væljuz ɑɹ: tɛn kɑpɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ pɛni; wʌnhʌnʒɹəd sɪlvɝ pɛniz ikwəlz lsɪlvɝ mɑɹk; tɛn sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊn; tɛn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl mɑɹk; tɛn ɡoʊl mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn. baɪ kɑntʃɹæst, ɪn ɔltɑɹə, wɛɹ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ kɔɪnz kənteɪn lɛs ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, ðə ɹɛləɾɪv væljuz ɑɹ: tɛn kɑpɝ pɛniz ikwəlzwʌn sɪlvɝ pɛni; twɛntiwʌn sɪlvɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ mɑɹk; twɛnti sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊn; twɛnti sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl mɑɹk; twɛnti ɡoʊl mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn.

The heaviest coins come from Andor and Tar Valon, and in those two places the relative values are: 10 copper pennies = 1 silver penny; 100 silver pennies = lsilver mark; 10 silver marks = 1 silver crown; 10 silver crowns = 1 gold mark; 10 gold marks = 1 gold crown. By contrast, in Altara, where the larger coins contain less gold or silver, the relative values are: 10 copper pennies =1 silver penny; 21 silver pennies = 1 silver mark; 20 silver marks = 1 silver crown; 20 silver crowns = 1 gold mark; 20 gold marks = 1 gold crown.

ði oʊnli peɪpɝ kɝənsi ɪz "lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts," wɪtʃ ɑɹ ɪʃud baɪ bæŋkɝz, ɡɛɹəntiɪŋ tə pɹizɛn ə sɝɾən əmaʊn ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ wən ðə lɛɾɝ-ʌv-ɹaɪts ɪz pɹizɛntəd. kəz ə ðə lɔŋ dɪstənsəz bɪtwin sɪɾiz, ðə lɛŋθ ə taɪm niɾəd tə tʃɹævəl fɹəm wʌn tə ənʌðɝ, ən ðə dɪfəkəltiz ə tʃɹænzækʃənz ət lɔŋ dɪstəns, ə lɛɾɝ-ʌv-ɹaɪts meɪ bi æksɛptɪɾ ət fʊl vælju ɪn ə sɪɾi nɪɹ tə ðə bæŋk wɪtʃ ɪʃuɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt meɪ oʊnli bi æksɛptɪɾ əɾ ə loʊɝ vælju ɪn ə sɪɾi fɑɹðɝ əweɪ. dʒɛnɝəli, sʌmwʌn ɪntɛndɪŋ tə bi tʃɹævlɪŋ fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm wɪl kæɹi wʌn əɹ mɔɹ lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ kɔɪn wən niɾəd. lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts ɑɹ juʒəwəli æksɛptɪɾ oʊnli baɪ bæŋkɝz əɹ mɝtʃəns, ən wəd nɛvɝ bi juzd ɪn ʃɑps.

The only paper currency is "letters-of-rights," which are issued by bankers, guaranteeing to present a certain amount of gold or silver when the letter-of-rights is presented. Because of the long distances between cities, the length of time needed to travel from one to another, and the difficulties of transactions at long distance, a letter-of-rights may be accepted at full value in a city near to the bank which issued it, but it may only be accepted at a lower value in a city farther away. Generally, someone intending to be traveling for a long time will carry one or more letters-of-rights to exchange for coin when needed. Letters-of-rights are usually accepted only by bankers or merchants, and would never be used in shops.

dækoʊvæl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wʌn u ɪz oʊnd," əɹ "pɝsən u ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə tɝm ɔfən juzd, əlɔŋ wɪð "pɹɑpɝɾi," fəɹ sleɪvz. sleɪvɝi hæz ə lɔŋ ən ənjuʒəwəl hɪstɝi əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, wɪð sleɪvz hævɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə ɹaɪz tə pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən oʊpən əθɔɹəɾi, ɪnkluɾɪŋ əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðoʊz u ɑɹ fɹi. ɪts ɔlsoʊ pɑsəbəl fəɹ ðoʊz ɪn pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ tə bi ɹədus tə dækoʊvæl. si ɔlsoʊ sɔɪhɪn.

da'covale: (1) In the Old Tongue, "one who is owned," or "person who is property." (2) Among the Seanchan, the term often used, along with "property," for slaves. Slavery has a long and unusual history among the Seanchan, with slaves having the ability to rise to positions of great power and open authority, including authority over those who are free. It is also possible for those in positions of great power to be reduced to da'covale. See also so'jhin.

dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ boʊθ hjumənz ən oʊɡiɝ. ðə hjumən mɛmbɝz ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹɾ ɑɹ ɔl dækoʊvæl, bɔɹn əz pɹɑpɝɾi ən tʃoʊzən waɪl jʌŋ tə sɝv ði ɛmpɹɛs, huz pɝsənəl pɹɑpɝɾi ðeɪ ɑɹ. fənæɾɪkəli lɔɪəl ən fɪɹsli pɹaʊd, ðeɪ ɔfən dɪspleɪ ðə ɹeɪvənz tætuɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ðə mɑɹk ʌv ə dækoʊvæl ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. ði oʊɡiɝ mɛmbɝz ɑɹ noʊn əz ɡɑɹɾənɝz, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt dækoʊvæl. ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz ɑɹ əz fɪɹsli lɔɪəl əz ðə hjumən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðoʊ, ən ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ fɪɹd.

Deathwatch Guards, the: The elite military formation of the Seanchan Empire, including both humans and Ogier. The human members of the Deathwatch Guard are all da'covale, born as property and chosen while young to serve the Empress, whose personal property they are. Fanatically loyal and fiercely proud, they often display the ravens tattooed on their shoulders, the mark of a da'covale of the Empress. The Ogier members are known as Gardeners, and they are not da'covale. The Gardeners are as fiercely loyal as the human Deathwatch Guards, though, and are even more feared.

hjumən əɹ oʊɡiɝ, ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz nɑɾ oʊnli ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə daɪ fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs ən ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, bʌt bɪliv ðət ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑɹ ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ði ɛmpɹɛs, tə bi dɪspoʊzd ʌv əz ʃi wɪʃɪz.

Human or Ogier, the Deathwatch Guards not only are ready to die for the Empress and the Imperial family, but believe that their lives are the property of the Empress, to be disposed of as she wishes.

ðɛɹ hɛlməts ən ɑɹmɝ ɑɹ lækɝɾ ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin (soʊ dɑɹk ðəɾ ɪts ɔfən mɪsteɪkənli kɔl blæk)

Their helmets and armor are lacquered in dark green (so dark that it is often mistakenly called black)

ən blʌd ɹɛd, ðɛɹ ʃilz ɑɹ lækɝd blæk, ən ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, spɪɹz, æksiz ən hælbɝdz kæɹi blæk tæsəlz. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

and blood red, their shields are lacquered black, and their swords, spears, axes and halberds carry black tassels. See also da'covale.

dɛlvɪŋ: (wʌn) juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə daɪəɡnoʊs fɪzɪkəl kəndɪʃən ən ɪlnəs. (tu) faɪndɪŋ dəpɑzɪts ə mɛɾəl ɔɹz wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðət ðɪs əz lɔŋ bɪn ə lɔst əbɪləɾi əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ əkaʊn fəɹ ðə neɪm bɪkʌmɪŋ ətætʃt tə ənʌðɝ əbɪləɾi.

Delving: (1) Using the One Power to diagnose physical condition and illness. (2) Finding deposits of metal ores with the One Power. That this has long been a lost ability among Aes Sedai may account for the name becoming attached to another ability.

dɝmɝæt-: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "mæstɝ hænlɝ." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə pɹifɪks əplaɪd tə ɪndəkeɪɾ ə sinjɝ ən haɪli skɪl hænlɝ ʌv wʌn ə ði ɛɡzɑɾɪks, wʌn u tʃɹeɪnz ʌðɝz, əz ɪn dɝmɝətʃɹeɪkən.

der'morat-: (1) In the Old Tongue, "master handler." (2) Among the Seanchan, the prefix applied to indicate a senior and highly skilled handler of one of the exotics, one who trains others, as in der'morat'raken.

dɝmɝæt kən əv ə fɛɹli haɪ soʊʃəl stæɾəs, ðə haɪəst ʌv ɔl hɛl baɪ dɝsʌldəm, ðə tʃɹeɪnɝz ə sʌldəm, hu ɹæŋk wɪð fɛɹli haɪ mɪlətɛɹi ɔfəsɝz. si ɔlsoʊ mɔɝæt-.

Der'morat can have a fairly high social status, the highest of all held by der'sul'dam, the trainers of sul'dam, who rank with fairly high military officers. See also morat-.

dʒɹæɡən: ə paʊɝfəl nu wɛpən keɪpəbəl ə faɪɹɪŋ ɪksploʊsɪv tʃɑɹdʒəz oʊvɝ lɑɹdʒ dɪstənsəz, kɑzɪŋ ɪkstɛnsɪv dæmədʒ tə ði ɛnəmi.

dragon: A powerful new weapon capable of firing explosive charges over large distances, causing extensive damage to the enemy.

dʒɹæɡənz' ɛɡz: ðə neɪm ɡɪvən tə ði ɪksploʊsɪv tʃɑɹdʒəz faɪɝd baɪ dʒɹæɡənz.

dragons' eggs: The name given to the explosive charges fired by dragons.

ɛlfɪn: ə ɹeɪs ə biɪŋz, lɑɹdʒli hjumən ɪn əpɪɹəns bʌt wɪð fɑks-laɪk kɛɹəktɝɪstɪks, hu wɪl ɡɹæn θɹi wɪʃɪz, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ æsk fəɹ ə pɹaɪs ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ɪf ðə pɝsən æskɪŋ dʌz nɑt nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ ə pɹaɪs, ði ɛlfɪn tʃuz ɪt. ðə moʊs kɑmən pɹaɪs ɪn sətʃ sɝkəmstænsəz ɪz dɛθ, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl fʊlfɪl ðɛɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən, ɔlðoʊ ðə mænɝ ɪn wɪtʃ ðeɪ fʊlfɪl ɪts sɛldəm ðə mænɝ ðə wʌn æskɪŋ ɪkspɛks. ðɛɹ tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə vɪzəɾ əm baɪ minz ʌv ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət wɑz loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ɹɪɾiən. ðət tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz teɪkən baɪ mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd tə kɛɹhin, wɛɹ ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ðeɪ meɪ ɔlsoʊ bi ɹitʃt baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. ðeɪ æsk ðə seɪm kwɛstʃənz əz ði æɛlfɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ faɪɝ, aɪɝn, ən mjuzɪkəl ɪnstʃɹəməns. si ɔlsoʊ æɛlfɪn, sneɪks ən fɑksəz.

Eelfinn: A race of beings, largely human in appearance but with fox-like characteristics, who will grant three wishes, although they ask for a price in return. If the person asking does not negotiate a price, the Eelfinn choose it. The most common price in such circumstances is death, but they still fulfill their part of the bargain, although the manner in which they fulfill it is seldom the manner the one asking expects. Their true location is unknown, but it was possible to visit them by means of a ter'angreal that was located in Rhuidean. That ter'angreal was taken by Moiraine Damodred to Cairhien, where it was destroyed. They may also be reached by entering the Tower of Ghenjei. They ask the same questions as the Aelfinn regarding fire, iron, and musical instruments. See also Aelfinn, Snakes and Foxes.

fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, dʒaɪn: ə hɪɹoʊ ʌv ðə nɔɹðɝn lænz u dʒɝnid tə mɛni lænz ən hæd mɛni ædvɛntʃɝz; hi kæptʃɝd kaʊɪn fɛɹhɑɹɾ ən bɹɔɾ ɪm tə ðə kɪŋz dʒʌstəs. hi wɑz ði ɔθɝ ə sɛvɹəl bʊks, əz wɛl əz ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə bʊks ən stɔɹiz. hi vænɪʃt ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədeɪtiwʌn ni, æftɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ə tʃɹɪp ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt wɪtʃ səm sɛd hæd teɪkən ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

Farstrider, Jain: A hero of the northern lands who journeyed to many lands and had many adventures; he captured Cowin Fairheart and brought him to the king's justice. He was the author of several books, as well as the subject of books and stories. He vanished in 981 NE, after returning from a trip into the Great Blight which some said had taken him all the way to Shayol Ghul.

fɛl, hɹɪd: ði ɔθɝ ə ɹizən ən ənɹisən ən ʌðɝ bʊks. fɛl wɑz ə stuɾənt (æn titʃɝ)

Fel, Herid: The author of Reason and Unreason and other books. Fel was a student (and teacher)

ʌv hɪstɝi ən fəlɑsəfi ət ði əkæɾəmi ʌv kɛɹhin. hi wɑz dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ɪz stʌɾi tɔɹn lɪm fɹəm lɪm.

of history and philosophy at the Academy of Cairhien. He was discovered in his study torn limb from limb.

fɝst ɹizənɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ fɛɹən nhɝən.

First Reasoner: The title given to the head of the White Ajah. This position is currently held by Ferane Neheran.

fɝst səlɛktɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə blu ədʒɑ. ðə fɝst səlɛktɝ ɪz kɝənli ənnoʊn, ɔlðoʊ ɪts səspɛktəd ðət ləleɪn əkɑʃi fɪlz ðɪs pəzɪʃən.

First Selector: The title given to the head of the Blue Ajah. The First Selector is currently unknown, although it is suspected that Lelaine Akashi fills this position.

fɝst wivɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ swænə dʒɹeɪɡən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

First Weaver: The title given to the head of the Yellow Ajah. This position is currently held by Suana Dragand in the White Tower.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: ðə neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ən wɝ tʃɹæpt ɪn ðə silɪŋ ə ðə bɔɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. waɪl ɪts lɔŋ bɪn bɪliv ðət ðeɪ əloʊn əbændən ðə laɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪn fækt ʌðɝz dɪɾ əz wɛl; ðiz θɝtin wɝ oʊnli ðə haɪəst-ɹæŋkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðə fɔɹseɪkən (hu kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə tʃoʊzən) ɑɹ sʌmwʌt ɹədust ɪn nʌmbɝ sɪns ðɛɹ əweɪkənɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹɛzən deɪ. səm ə ðoʊz kɪld wɝ ɹiɪnkɑɹneɪɾɪd ɪn nu bɑɾiz.

Forsaken, the: The name given to thirteen powerful Aes Sedai, men and women both, who went over to the Shadow during the Age of Legends and were trapped in the sealing of the Bore into the Dark One's prison. While it has long been believed that they alone abandoned the Light during the War of the Shadow, in fact others did as well; these thirteen were only the highest-ranking among them. The Forsaken (who call themselves the Chosen) are somewhat reduced in number since their awakening in the present day. Some of those killed were reincarnated in new bodies.

ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn, ðə: ðə bænɝ ə ðə lɔs bɔɹɾɝlənd neɪʃən ə mɔlkiɝ.

Golden Crane, the: The banner of the lost Borderland nation of Malkier.

ɡɹeɪndəl: wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. wʌns noʊn əz kɑmɝəl mɛɹɑdim nɪn-dɑɹ, ə noʊɾəd əsɛɾɪk, ʃi wɑz ðə sɛkən ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən tə dɪsaɪd tə sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ə ɹuθləs kɪlɝ, ʃi wɑz ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðə dɛθs ə ɝæŋɡɝ ən æzmɑɾiən ən fəɹ ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə mɛsænə. hɝ pɹɛzən sɝkəmstænsəz ɑɹ ənsɝɾən.

Graendal: One of the Forsaken. Once known as Kamarile Maradim Nin-dar, a noted ascetic, she was the second of the Forsaken to decide to serve the Dark One. A ruthless killer, she was responsible for the deaths of Aran'gar and Asmodean and for the destruction of Mesaana. Her present circumstances are uncertain.

bɑdɔɹi: ðə bɹeɪɾɪd lɛðɝ kɔɹd ðəɾ ə mɔlkɪɹi mæn taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz tɛmpəlz tə hoʊld ɪz hɛɹ bæk. əntɪl æftɝ mɔlkiɝ fɛl tə ðə blaɪt, ɛvɹi ədʌl mɔlkɪɹi meɪl wɔɹ ɪz hɛɹ tə ðə ʃoʊldɝz ən taɪd bæk wɪð ə hædɔɹi. laɪk ðə pɹɛzənteɪʃən ə hɪz sɔɹd, biɪŋ əlaʊd tə wɛɹ ðə bɑdɔɹi mɑɹk ðə muv fɹəm tʃaɪldhʊd tə ədʌlthʊd fəɹ mɔlkɪɹi meɪlz. ðə bɑdɔɹi sɪmbəlaɪz ðə duɾiz ən ɑbləɡeɪʃənz ðət baʊn ɪm əz ən ədʌlt, ən ɔlsoʊ hɪz kənɛkʃən tə mɔlkiɝ. si ɔlsoʊ kɪsən.

badori: The braided leather cord that a Malkieri man tied around his temples to hold his hair back. Until after Malkier fell to the Blight, every adult Malkieri male wore his hair to the shoulders and tied back with a hadori. Like the presentation of his sword, being allowed to wear the badori marked the move from childhood to adulthood for Malkieri males. The badori symbolized the duties and obligations that bound him as an adult, and also his connection to Malkier. See also ki'sain.

hænlən, dɑvd: eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ, hu wɑz kæptʃɝd wɪð leɪɾi ʃieɪn, tʃɛzməl ɛmɹi, ɛlʒɹɪθ ɑndɑɹ, təmeɪl kɪndɝəd, fæljən boʊɾə ən mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn.

Hanlon, Daved: A Darkfriend, also known as Doilin Mellar, who was captured with Lady Shiaine, Chesmal Emry, Eldrith Jhondar, Temaile Kinderode, Falion Bhoda and Marillin Gemalphin.

hɛd klɝk: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ sɹæntʃə kɑlvaɪn.

Head Clerk: The title given to the head of the Gray Ajah. This position is currently held by Serancha Colvine.

hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt kaʊnsəl ə θɝtin: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ ɑlviɛɝɪn fɹaɪɾən.

Head of the Great Council of Thirteen: The title given to the head of the Black Ajah. This position is currently held by Alviarin Freidhen.

hɑɹt: ðə beɪsɪk junəɾ ʌv ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ɪn ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ɪn ɪfɛkt, ə sɛl. ə hɑɹt kənsɪsts ə θɹi sɪstɝz u noʊ itʃ ʌðɝ, wɪð itʃ mɛmbɝ ə ðə hɑɹt noʊɪŋ wʌn ədɪʃənəl sɪstɝ ə ðə blæk u ɪz ənnoʊn tə ði ʌðɝ tu ʌv əɹ hɑɹt.

heart: The basic unit of organization in the Black Ajah. In effect, a cell. A heart consists of three sisters who know each other, with each member of the heart knowing one additional sister of the Black who is unknown to the other two of her heart.

haɪəst: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ tsutɑmə ɹæθ.

Highest: The title given to the head of the Red Ajah. This position is currently held by Tsutama Rath.

ɪluməneɪɾɝz, ɡɪld ʌv: ə səsaɪəɾi ðət hɛl ðə sikɹəɾ ə meɪkɪŋ faɪɹwɝks. ɪt ɡɑɹɾəd ðɪs sikɹət vɛɹi kloʊsli, ivən tə ði ɪkstɛn ə duɪŋ mɝɾɝ tə pɹətɛkt ɪt. ðə ɡɪld ɡeɪn ɪts neɪm fɹəm ðə ɡɹæn dɪspleɪz, kɔld ɪluməneɪʃənz, ðəɾ ɪt pɹəvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹulɝz ən səmtaɪmz fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾɝ lɔɹdz.

Illuminators, Guild of: A society that held the secret of making fireworks. It guarded this secret very closely, even to the extent of doing murder to protect it. The Guild gained its name from the grand displays, called Illuminations, that it provided for rulers and sometimes for greater lords.

lɛsɝ faɪɹwɝks wɝ soʊl fəɹ jus baɪ ʌðɝz, bʌt wɪð daɪɹ wɔɹnɪŋz ə ðə dɪzæstɝ ðət kəd ɹɪzʌl fɹəm ətɛmptɪŋ tə lɝn wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðɛm. ðə ɡɪld wʌns hæd tʃæptɝ haʊsəz ɪn kɛɹhin ən tæntʃəkoʊ, bʌt boʊθ ɑɹ naʊ dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ɪn ədɪʃən, ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə ɡɪld ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɪnveɪʒən baɪ ðə sintʃæn ən wɝ meɪd dækoʊvæl, ən ðə ɡɪld əz sətʃ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪsts. haʊɛvɝ, ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ɪluməneɪɾɝz stɪl ɪɡzɪst aʊtsaɪɾ ə sintʃæn ɹul ən wɝk tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ðə ɡɪld wɪl bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

Lesser fireworks were sold for use by others, but with dire warnings of the disaster that could result from attempting to learn what was inside them. The Guild once had chapter houses in Cairhien and Tanchico, but both are now destroyed. In addition, the members of the Guild in Tanchico resisted the invasion by the Seanchan and were made da'covale, and the Guild as such no longer exists. However, individual Illuminators still exist outside of Seanchan rule and work to make sure that the Guild will be remembered. See also da'covale.

ɪmfɹəl: ðə sɪksθ-lɑɹdʒəst sɪɾi ʌv sintʃæn. ɪts loʊkeɪɾəd nɔɹθwɛst ə sindɑɹ, ən ɪz hoʊm tə ðə taʊɝz ə mɪdnaɪt. si ɔlsoʊ taʊɝz ə mɪdnaɪt.

Imfaral: The sixth-largest city of Seanchan. It is located northwest of Seandar, and is home to the Towers of Midnight. See also Towers of Midnight.

kɪsən: ə smɔl mɑɹk, ə dɑt, wɪtʃ ən ədʌl mɔlkɪɹi wʊmən peɪntəɾ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛɾ itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn plɛdʒ ðət ʃi wəd swɛɹ (ɔɹ hæd swɔɹn) hɝ sʌnz tə faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ. ðɪs plɛdʒ wɑz nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli ðət ðeɪ wəd bi wɔɹiɝz, bʌt ðət ðeɪ wəɾ əpoʊz ðə ʃædoʊ ɛvɹi deɪ ɪn ɛvɹi weɪ ðət ðeɪ kʊd. laɪk ðə hædɔɹi, ðə kɪsən wɑz ɔlsoʊ kənsɪɾɝd ə sɪmbəl ə kənɛkʃən tə mɔlkiɝ, ən ə ðə bɑnz ðət junaɪɾəd əɹ wɪð ʌðɝ mɔlkɪɹi. ɔlsoʊ laɪk ðə hɑ-dɔɹi, ðə kɪsən wɑz ə saɪn ʌv ədʌlthʊd. ðə kɪsən ɔlsoʊ ɡeɪv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt ðə wʊmən u wɔɹ ɪt. ə blu mɑɹk wɑz wɔɹn baɪ ə wʊmən u hæd nɑt mɛɹid, ə ɹɛd mɑɹk baɪ ə mɛɹid wʊmən ən ə waɪt mɑɹk baɪ ə wɪɾoʊ. ɪn dɛθ, ʃi wəd bi mɑɹkt wɪð ɔl θɹi, wʌn ʌv itʃ kʌlɝ, wɛðɝ ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛɹiɾ əɹ nɑt. si ɔlsoʊ hædɔɹi.

ki'sain: A small mark, a dot, which an adult Malkieri woman painted on her forehead each morning in pledge that she would swear (or had sworn) her sons to fight the Shadow. This pledge was not necessarily that they would be warriors, but that they would oppose the Shadow every day in every way that they could. Like the hadori, the ki'sain was also considered a symbol of connection to Malkier, and of the bonds that united her with other Malkieri. Also like the ha-dori, the ki'sain was a sign of adulthood. The ki'sain also gave information about the woman who wore it. A blue mark was worn by a woman who had not married, a red mark by a married woman and a white mark by a widow. In death, she would be marked with all three, one of each color, whether she had ever married or not. See also hadori.

lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ə lɑɹdʒ mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən, ɔl ɪnfəntʃɹi, ɡɪvɪŋ əlidʒəns tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, tʃɹeɪn baɪ dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ əlɔŋ laɪnz wɝkt aʊt baɪ hɪmsɛlf ən mæt kɔθən, laɪnz wɪtʃ dɪpɑɹt ʃɑɹpli fɹəm ðə juʒəwəl ɛmplɔɪmən ə fʊt. waɪl mɛni mɛn sɪmpli wɔk ɪn tə vɑləntɪɹ, lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə ðə lidʒən ɑɹ skupt ʌp baɪ ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz fɹəm ðə blæk taʊɝ, hu fɝst ɡæðɝ ɔl ə ðə mɛn ɪn ən ɛɹiə hu wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən oʊnli æftɝ teɪkɪŋ əm θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn wɪnoʊ aʊt ðoʊz u kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ, baɪ fɑɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ, ɑɹ sɛn tə bæʃɪɹz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ kæmps. ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ət pɹɛzən tʃɹeɪnɪŋ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

Legion of the Dragon, the: A large military formation, all infantry, giving allegiance to the Dragon Reborn, trained by Davram Bashere along lines worked out by himself and Mat Cauthon, lines which depart sharply from the usual employment of foot. While many men simply walk in to volunteer, large numbers of the Legion are scooped up by recruiting parties from the Black Tower, who first gather all of the men in an area who were willing to follow the Dragon Reborn, and only after taking them through gateways near Caemlyn winnow out those who can be taught to channel. The remainder, by far the greater number, are sent to Bashere's training camps. The Legion of the Dragon is at present training for the Last Battle.

lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv: tɛn ɪntʃəz ikwəlz wʌn fʊt; θɹi fiɾ ikwəlz wʌn peɪs; tu peɪsɪz ikwəlz wʌn spæn; wʌnθaʊzən spænz ikwəlz wʌn maɪl; fɔɹ

length, units of: 10 inches = 1 foot; 3 feet = 1 pace; 2 paces = 1 span; 1000 spans = 1 mile; 4

maɪlz  wʌn liɡ.

miles = 1 league.

lɪsənɝz: eɪ sintʃæn spaɪ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən. ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə haʊshoʊld ʌv ə sintʃæn noʊbəl, mɝtʃən əɹ bæŋkɝ meɪ bi ə lɪsənɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dækoʊvæl əkeɪʒənəli, ðoʊ sɛldəm sɔɪtn. ðeɪ teɪk noʊ æktɪv ɹoʊl, mɪɹli wɑtʃɪŋ, lɪsnɪŋ ən ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ. ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ sɛn tə lɛsɝ hænz u kəntʃɹoʊl boʊθ əm ən ðə sikɝz ən dɪsaɪd wʌt ʃəd bi pæst ɑn tə ðə sikɝz fəɹ fɝðɝ ækʃən. si ɔlsoʊ sikɝz.

Listeners: A Seanchan spy organization. Almost anyone in the household of a Seanchan noble, merchant or banker may be a Listener, including da'covale occasionally, though seldom so'jhtn. They take no active role, merely watching, listening and reporting. Their reports are sent to Lesser Hands who control both them and the Seekers and decide what should be passed on to the Seekers for further action. See also Seekers.

mɛɹəθdətnən: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u mʌs bi liʃt," ən ɔlsoʊ "wʌn u mʌs bi liʃt." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ɛni wʊmən keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ u hæz nɑt bɪn kɑlɝɾ əz ə deɪmeɪn.

marath'datnane: In the Old Tongue, "those who must be leashed," and also "one who must be leashed." The term applied by the Seanchan to any woman capable of channeling who has not been collared as a damane.

mɑɹtʃ: si ɛɹiə, junəts ʌv.

march: See area, units of.

mɛlɝ, dɔɪlɪn: si hænlən, dɑvd.

Mellar, Doilin: See Hanlon, Daved.

mɛɝeɪɾɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bɹʌðɝləs." ðə neɪm ədɑptəd, əz ə səsaɪəɾi, baɪ ðoʊz il u əbændən klæn ən sɛpt ən wɛn tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɹænd ælθɹ, ə wɛtləndɝ, əz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, əɹ kəz ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə hɪstɝi ən ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ði il. dɛzɝɾɪŋ klæn ən sɛp fəɹ ɛni ɹizən ɪz ənæθəmə əmʌŋ ði il, ðɛɹfɔɹ ðɛɹ oʊn wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ənwɪlɪŋ tə teɪk əm ɪn, ən ðeɪ fɔɹm ðɪs səsaɪəɾi, ðə bɹʌðɝləs.

Mera'din: In the Old Tongue, "the Brotherless." The name adopted, as a society, by those Aiel who abandoned clan and sept and went to the Shaido because they could not accept Rand al'Thor, a wetlander, as the Car'a'carn, or because they refused to accept his revelations concerning the history and origins of the Aiel. Deserting clan and sept for any reason is anathema among the Aiel, therefore their own warrior societies among the Shaido were unwilling to take them in, and they formed this society, the Brotherless.

mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd: eɪ kɛɹhinɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. lɔŋ pɹəzum dɛd. θɔɹn mɛɹɪlɪn hæz, haʊɛvɝ, ɹɪvil ðə ɹɪsiɾ ʌv ə lɛɾɝ pɝpɔɹɾɪŋ tə bi fɹəm hɝ. ɪts ɹipɹədus hɪɹ:

Moiraine Damodred: A Cairhienin Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah. Long presumed dead. Thorn Merrilin has, however, revealed the receipt of a letter purporting to be from her. It is reproduced here:

maɪ dɪɹəs θɔɹn, ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni wɝdz aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɹaɪt tə ju, wɝdz fɹəm maɪ hɑɹt, bʌɾ aɪ hæv pʊt ðɪs ɔf kəz aɪ nu ðəɾ aɪ mʌst, ən naʊ ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl taɪm. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni θɪŋz aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə lɛst aɪ bɹɪŋ dɪzæstɝ, bʌt wʌɾ aɪ kæn, aɪ wɪl. hid kɛɹfəli wʌɾ aɪ seɪ. ɪn ə ʃɔɹt waɪl əl ɡoʊ daʊn tə ðə dɑks, ən ðəɹ əl kənfɹʌn lænfɝ. haʊ kən aɪ noʊ ðæt? ðət sikɹət bɪlɔŋz tə ʌðɝz. səfaɪs ɪt ðəɾ aɪ noʊ, ən lɛt ðət fɹknoʊlɪdʒ stæn əz pɹuf fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌɾ aɪ seɪ.

My dearest Thorn, There are many words I would like to write to you, words from my heart, but I have put this off because I knew that I must, and now there is little time. There are many things I cannot tell you lest I bring disaster, but what I can, I will. Heed carefully what I say. In a short while I will go down to the docks, and there I will confront Lanfear. How can I know that? That secret belongs to others. Suffice it that I know, and let that foreknowledge stand as proof for the rest of what I say.

wən jə ɹəsiv ðɪs, jəl bi toʊl ðəɾ aɪm dɛd. ɔl wɪl bɪliv ðæt. aɪm nɑt dɛd, ən ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ aɪ ʃæl lɪv tə maɪ əpɔɪntəd jɪɹz. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ meɪ bi ðət jə ən mæt kɔθən ən ənʌðɝ, ə mæn aɪ də nɑt noʊ, wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɛskju mi. meɪ, aɪ seɪ kəz ɪt meɪ bi ðət jəl nɑɾ əɹ kænɑt, əɹ kəz mæt meɪ ɹəfjuz. hi dʌz nɑt hoʊl mi ɪn ði əfɛkʃən jə sim tə, ən hiz ɪz ɹizənz wɪtʃ i noʊ daʊt θɪŋks ɑɹ ɡʊd. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ, ɪt mʌs bi oʊnli jə ən mæt ən wʌn ʌðɝ. mɔɹ wɪl min dɛθ fəɹ ɔl. fjuɝ wɪl min dɛθ fəɹ ɔl.

When you receive this, you will be told that I am dead. All will believe that. I am not dead, and it may be that I shall live to my appointed years. It also may be that you and Mat Cauthon and another, a man I do not know, will try to rescue me. May, I say because it may be that you will not or cannot, or because Mat may refuse. He does not hold me in the affection you seem to, and he has his reasons which he no doubt thinks are good. If you try, it must be only you and Mat and one other. More will mean death for all. Fewer will mean death for all.

ivən ɪf jə kʌm oʊnli wɪð mæt ən wʌn ʌðɝ, dɛθ ɔlsoʊ meɪ kʌm. aɪ hæv sin jə tʃɹaɪ ən daɪ, wʌn əɹ tu əɹ ɔl θɹi. aɪ hæv sin maɪsɛlf daɪ ɪn ði ətɛmpt. aɪ hæv sin ɔl ʌv əs lɪv ən daɪ əz kæptɪvz. ʃəd jə dɪsaɪd tə meɪk ði ətɛmpt ɛniweɪ, jʌŋ mæt noʊz ðə weɪ tə faɪn mi, jɛt jə mʌs nɑt ʃoʊ hɪm ðɪs lɛɾɝ əntɪl i æsks əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ə ði ʌtmoʊst ɪmpɔɹɾəns. hi mʌs noʊ nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz ɪn ðɪs lɛɾɝ əntɪl i æsks. ɪvɛns mʌs pleɪ aʊɾ ɪn sɝɾən weɪz, wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑsts.

Even if you come only with Mat and one other, death also may come. I have seen you try and die, one or two or all three. I have seen myself die in the attempt. I have seen all of us live and die as captives. Should you decide to make the attempt anyway, young Mat knows the way to find me, yet you must not show him this letter until he asks about it. That is of the utmost importance. He must know nothing that is in this letter until he asks. Events must play out in certain ways, whatever the costs.

ɪf jə si læn əɡɛn, tɛl ɪm ðəɾ ɔl ə ðɪs ɪz fəɹ ðə bɛst. hɪz dɛstəni fɑloʊz ə dɪfɹən pæθ fɹəm maɪn. aɪ wɪʃ ɪm ɔl hæpinəs wɪð nɪneɪiv.

If you see Lan again, tell him that all of this is for the best. His destiny follows a different path from mine. I wish him all happiness with Nynaeve.

ə faɪnəl pɔɪnt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt jə noʊ əbaʊt ðə ɡeɪm ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən hid.

A final point. Remember what you know about the game of Snakes and Foxes. Remember, and heed.

ɪts taɪm, ən aɪ mʌs də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

It is time, and I must do what must be done.

meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin jə ən ɡɪv jə dʒɔɪ, maɪ dɪɹəs θɔɹn, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt wi ɛvɝ si wʌn ənʌðɝ əɡɛn.

May the Light illumine you and give you joy, my dearest Thorn, whether or not we ever see one another again.

mɔɪɹeɪn mɔɝæt-: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "hænlɝ." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ɪts juz fəɹ ðoʊz u hændəl ɛɡzɑɾɪks, sətʃ əz mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən, eɪ. ɹeɪkən hænlɝ əɹ ɹaɪɾɝ, ɔlsoʊ ɪnfɔɹməli kɔld ə flaɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ dɝmɝæt-.

Moiraine morat-: In the Old Tongue, "handler." Among the Seanchan, it is used for those who handle exotics, such as morat'raken, a. raken handler or rider, also informally called a flier. See also der'morat-.

pɹɑfət, ðə: mɔɹ fɔɹməli, ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. wʌns noʊn əz mæsimə dɑɡɝ, ə ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ, hi ʌndɝwɛn ə ɹɛvəleɪʃən ən dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ i hæd bɪn kɔl tə spɹɛd ðə wɝɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz ɹibɝθ. hi bɪliv ðət nʌθɪŋ - nʌθɪŋ! - wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz ðə laɪt meɪd flɛʃ ən biɪŋ ɹɛɾi wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kɔld, ən i ən ɪz fɑloʊɝz wəd juz ɛni minz tə fɔɹs ʌðɝz tə sɪŋ ðə ɡlɔɹiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðoʊz u ɹəfjuzd wɝ mɑɹk fəɹ dɛθ, ən ðoʊz u wɝ sloʊ maɪt faɪn ðɛɹ hoʊmz ən ʃɑps bɝn ən ðɛmsɛlvz flɑɡd. fɔɹseɪkɪŋ ɛni neɪm bʌt "ðə pɹɑfət," hi bɹɔt keɪɑs tə mʌtʃ ʌv ɡildən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə, lɑɹdʒ pɑɹts ʌv wɪtʃ i kəntʃɹoʊld, ɔlðoʊ wɪð ɪm ɡɔn, ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ɹiɪstæblɪʃɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən ðə kɹaʊn haɪ kaʊnsəl ɪn ɡildən. hi dʒɔɪnd wɪð pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, hu wɑz sɛn tə bɹɪŋ ɪm tə ɹænd, ænd, fəɹ ɹizənz ənnoʊn, steɪd wɪð ɪm ivən ðoʊ ðɪs dɪleɪɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ mɛn ən wɪmən ə ðə loʊəst sɔɹt; ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt soʊ wən ðeɪ wɝ pʊld ɪn baɪ hɪz kɝɪzmə, ðeɪ bɪkeɪm soʊ ʌndɝ ɪz ɪnfluəns. hi daɪɾ ʌndɝ mɪstɪɹiəs sɝkəmstænsəz.

Prophet, the: More formally, the Prophet of the Lord Dragon. Once known as Masema Dagar, a Shienaran soldier, he underwent a revelation and decided that he had been called to spread the word of the Dragon's Rebirth. He believed that nothing - nothing! - was more important than acknowledging the Dragon Reborn as the Light made flesh and being ready when the Dragon Reborn called, and he and his followers would use any means to force others to sing the glories of the Dragon Reborn. Those who refused were marked for death, and those who were slow might find their homes and shops burned and themselves flogged. Forsaking any name but "the Prophet," he brought chaos to much of Ghealdan and Amadicia, large parts of which he controlled, although with him gone, the Seanchan are reestablishing order in Amadicia and the Crown High Council in Ghealdan. He joined with Perrin Aybara, who was sent to bring him to Rand, and, for reasons unknown, stayed with him even though this delayed his going to the Dragon Reborn. He was followed by men and women of the lowest sort; if they were not so when they were pulled in by his charisma, they became so under his influence. He died under mysterious circumstances.

kwinz ɡɑɹdz, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ɪn ændɝ. ɪn pistaɪm ðə ɡɑɹɾ ɪz ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ əphoʊldɪŋ ðə kwinz lɔ ən kipɪŋ ðə pis əkɹɔs ændɝ. ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾ ɪnkluɾ ə ɹɛɾ ʌndɝkoʊt, ɡlimɪŋ meɪl ən pleɪɾ ɑɹmɝ, ə bɹɪljən ɹɛd kloʊk, ən ə kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət wɪð ə bɑɹd vaɪzɝ. haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝz wɛɹ nɑts ə ɹæŋk ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən ɡoʊldən laɪən-hɛd spɝz. ə ɹisən ədɪʃən tə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz ɪz ðə kwinz pɝsənəl bɑɾiɡɑɹd, wɪtʃ ɪz kəmpoʊzd ɪntaɪɝli ʌv wɪmən sɪns ði ɝɛst ʌv ɪts fɔɹmɝ kæptən, dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ. ðiz ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɛɹ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət junəfɔɹmz ðən ðɛɹ meɪl kaʊntɝpɑɹts, ɪnkluɾɪŋ bɹɔd-bɹɪm hæts wɪð waɪt plumz, ɹɛd-lækɝd bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts tʃɹɪmd ɪn waɪt, ən leɪs-ɛdʒ sæʃɪz bɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ.

Queen's Guards, the: The elite military formation in Andor. In peacetime the Guard is responsible for upholding the Queen's law and keeping the peace across Andor. The uniform of the Queen's Guard include a red undercoat, gleaming mail and plate armor, a brilliant red cloak, and a conical helmet with a barred visor. High-ranking officers wear knots of rank on their shoulder and golden lion-head spurs. A recent addition to the Queen's Guards is the Queen's personal bodyguard, which is composed entirely of women since the arrest of its former captain, Doilin Mellar. These Guardswomen wear much more elaborate uniforms than their male counterparts, including broad-brimmed hats with white plumes, red-lacquered breastplates and helmets trimmed in white, and lace-edged sashes bearing the White Lion of Andor.

kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə: ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðeɪ ɹəfɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt - ðeɪ ɪntɛnsli dɪslaɪk biɪŋ kɔl kwɛstʃənɝz - ən ðɛɹ əvaʊd pɝpəsəz ɑɹ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn dɪspjəteɪʃənz ən ənkʌvɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɪn ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt, ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mɛθəɾ ʌv ɪnkwaɪɹi ɪz tɔɹtʃɝ; ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mænɝ ɪz ðət ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ɔlɹɛɾi ən mʌst oʊnli meɪk ðɛɹ vɪktəm kənfɛs tə ɪt. ət taɪmz ðeɪ ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪntaɪɝli sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd, wɪtʃ kəmænz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə blʌd-ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk.

Questioners, the: An order within the Children of the Light. They refer to themselves as the Hand of the Light - they intensely dislike being called Questioners - and their avowed purposes are to discover the truth in disputations and uncover Darkfriends. In the search for truth and the Light, their normal method of inquiry is torture; their normal manner is that they know the truth already and must only make their victim confess to it. At times they act as if they are entirely separate from the Children and the Council of the Anointed, which commands the Children. Their sign is a blood-red shepherd's crook.

ɹɛdʒɹmz: soʊlʒɝz ə ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd, hu hæv bɪn tʃoʊzən aʊt fəɹ tɛmpɝɛɹi pəlis duɾi tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz ə ðə bæn kɑz noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɹ dæmədʒ ɪn ə taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ðə bæn əz stɑpt. soʊ neɪm bɪkɔz, waɪl ɑn duɾi, ðeɪ wɛɹ vɛɹi bɹɔd ɹɛɾ ɑɹmbænz ðət ɹitʃ fɹəm kʌf tə ɛlboʊ. juʒəwəli tʃoʊzən fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə moʊst ɪkspɪɹiənst ən ɹɪlaɪəbəl mɛn.

Redarms: Soldiers of the Band of the Red Hand, who have been chosen out for temporary police duty to make sure that other soldiers of the Band cause no trouble or damage in a town or village where the Band has stopped. So named because, while on duty, they wear very broad red armbands that reach from cuff to elbow. Usually chosen from among the most experienced and reliable men.

sɪns ɛni dæmədʒəz mʌs bi peɪd fəɹ baɪ ðə mɛn sɝvɪŋ əz ɹɛdʒɹmz, ðeɪ wɝk hɑɹd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɔl ɪz kwaɪəɾ ən pisfəl. si ɔlsoʊ ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ.

Since any damages must be paid for by the men serving as Redarms, they work hard to make sure all is quiet and peaceful. See also Shen an Calhar.

sɑldɑiə: ə neɪʃən ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ɪts kæpəɾəl ɪz mɛɹədɑn, ən ɪts ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪz noʊn əz ðə kɝdɑmɔɹə (fɹʌm ði oʊl tʌŋ fəɹ "hɑɹɾ ə ðə pipəl"). ɪts ɹul baɪ ə kɪŋ əɹ kwin, ən ɪz ə hɝɛɾətɛɹi mɑnɑɹki. ðə kɹaʊn haɪ kaʊnsəl, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə kaʊnsəl ə lɔɹdz, ædvaɪzɪz ən əsɪsts ðə mɑnɑɹk ɪn ædmɪnɪstɝɪŋ ðə neɪʃən. ðə hʌzbən əɹ waɪf ʌv ə sɑldəiən ɹulɝ ɪz nɑt sɪmpli ə kɑnsɔɹt, bʌɾ ən ɔlmoʊs koʊ-ikwəl ɹulɝ. sɑldɑiə ɪz kɝənli ɹul baɪ hɝ moʊst ɪlumən mædʒəsti, tɛnoʊbiə si bæʃɪɹ kæzɑɾi, kwin ə sɑldɑiə, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə laɪt, sɔɹɾ ə ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs kæzɑɾi ən leɪɾi ʌv ʃhɑnji, æsnɛl, kʌnwɔɹ ən ɡɑnɑi; hɝ mɑɹʃəl-dʒɛnɝəl ən ðə liɾɝ ə hɝ ɑɹmi ɪz əɹ ʌŋkəl ən ɛɹ, dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ, ɔlðoʊ hiz bɪn mɪsɪŋ fɹəm ɪz poʊs fəɹ səm taɪm.

Saldaea: A nation in the Borderlands. Its capital is Maradon, and its royal palace is known as the Cordamora (from the Old Tongue for "Heart of the People"). It is ruled by a king or queen, and is a hereditary monarchy. The Crown High Council, also known as the Council of Lords, advises and assists the monarch in administering the nation. The husband or wife of a Saldaean ruler is not simply a consort, but an almost co-equal ruler. Saldaea is currently ruled by Her Most Illumined Majesty, Tenobia si Bashere Kazadi, Queen of Saldaea, Defender of the Light, Sword of the Blightborder, High Seat of House Kazadi and Lady of Shahanyi, Asnelle, Kunwar and Ganai; her Marshal-General and the leader of her army is her uncle and heir, Davram Bashere, although he has been missing from his post for some time.

sindɑɹ: ði ɪmpɪɹiəl kæpəɾəl ə sintʃæn, loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ðə nɔɹθist ə ðə sintʃæn kɑntənənt. ɪts ɔlsoʊ ðə lɑɹdʒəst sɪɾi ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ʌv ɛmpɹɛs ɹɑɾənən, ɪt dɪsɛndəɾ ɪndə keɪɑs.

Seandar: The Imperial capital of Seanchan, located in the northeast of the Seanchan continent. It is also the largest city in the Empire. After the death of Empress Radhanan, it descended into chaos.

sikɝz: mɔɹ fɔɹməli, sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ə pəlisslæʃspaɪ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ə ðə sintʃæn ɪmpɪɹiəl θɹoʊn. ɔlðoʊ moʊst sikɝz ɑɹ dækoʊvæl ən ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, ðeɪv waɪd-ɹeɪnʒɪŋ paʊɝz. ivən wʌn ə ðə blʌd kən bi ɝɛstəd fəɹ feɪljɝ tə ænsɝ ɛni kwɛstʃən pʊt baɪ ə sikɝ, əɹ fəɹ feɪljɝ tə koʊɑpɝeɪt fʊli wɪð ə sikɝ, ðɪs læs dɛn baɪ ðə sikɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, sʌbʒɪkt oʊnli tə ɹivju baɪ ði ɛmpɹɛs. ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ sɛn tə lɛs hænz, hu kəntʃɹoʊl boʊθ əm ən ðə lɪsənɝz. moʊst sikɝz fi ðət ðə hænz də nɑt pæs ɑn əz mʌtʃ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əz ðeɪ ʃul ənlaɪk ðə lɪsənɝz', ðə sikɝz' ɹoʊl ɪz æktɪv. ðoʊz sikɝz w ɑɹ dækoʊvæl ɑɹ mɑɹkt ɑn iðɝ ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə ɹeɪvən ən ə toʊ ənlaɪk ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, sikɝz ɑɹ sɛldəm iɡɝ tə ʃoʊ ðɛɹ ɹeɪvənz, ɪn pɑɹt kəz ɪt nəsɛsəteɪts ɹɪvilɪŋ u ən wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ. si ɔlsoʊ lɪsənɝz.

Seekers: More formally, Seekers for Truth, they are a police/spy organization of the Seanchan Imperial Throne. Although most Seekers are da'covale and the property of the Imperial family, they have wide-ranging powers. Even one of the Blood can be arrested for failure to answer any question put by a Seeker, or for failure to cooperate fully with a Seeker, this last denned by the Seekers themselves, subject only to review by the Empress. Their reports are sent to Lesse Hands, who control both them and the Listeners. Most Seekers fee that the Hands do not pass on as much information as they shoul Unlike the Listeners', the Seekers' role is active. Those Seekers wh are da'covale are marked on either shoulder with a raven and a towe Unlike the Deathwatch Guards, Seekers are seldom eager to sho~ their ravens, in part because it necessitates revealing who and what they are. See also Listeners.

ʃɑɹə: ə mɪstɪɹiəs læn tə ði ist ə ði il weɪst wɪtʃ ɪz ðə sɔɹs ə sɪlk ən aɪvɝi, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ tʃɹeɪd ɡʊdz. ðə læn ɪz pɹətɛktəd boʊθ baɪ ɪnhɑspəɾəbəl nætʃɹəl fitʃɝz ən baɪ mæn- meɪd wɔlz. lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn əbaʊt ʃɑɹə, əz ðə pipəl ə ðət lænd wɝk tə kip ðɛɹ kʌltʃɝ sikɹət.

Shara: A mysterious land to the east of the Aiel Waste which is the source of silk and ivory, among other trade goods. The land is protected both by inhospitable natural features and by man- made walls. Little is known about Shara, as the people of that land work to keep their culture secret.

ðə ʃɝɑnz dɪnaɪ ðət ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz tʌtʃt ðɛm, dɪspaɪɾ il steɪtməns tə ðə kɑntʃɹɛɹi. ðeɪ dɪnaɪ nɑlədʒ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ətɛmptəɾ ɪnveɪʒən, dɪspaɪt ði əkaʊns ʌv aɪwɪtnəsɪz fɹəm ðə si foʊk. ðə lɪɾəl ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðəɾ əz likt aʊt ɹɪvilz ðət ðə ʃɝɑnz ɑɹ ɹul baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl æbsəlut mɑnɑɹk, ə boʊn ɪf ə wʊmən ən ə boʊɾ ɪf ə mæn. ðət mɑnɑɹk ɹulz fəɹ ɪɡzækli sɛvən jɪɹz, ðən daɪz. ðə ɹul ðən pæsəz tə ðə meɪɾ ə ðət ɹulɝ, hu ɹulz fəɹ sɛvən jɪɹz ən ðən daɪz. ðɪs pæɾɝn əz ɹɪpiɾɪd ɪtsɛlf sɪns ðə taɪm ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðə ʃɝɑnz bɪliv ðət ðə dɛθs ɑɹ ðə "wɪl ə ðə pæɾɝn."

The Sharans deny that the Trolloc Wars touched them, despite Aiel statements to the contrary. They deny knowledge of Artur Hawkwing's attempted invasion, despite the accounts of eyewitnesses from the Sea Folk. The little information that has leaked out reveals that the Sharans are ruled by a single absolute monarch, a Sh'boan if a woman and a Sh'botay if a man. That monarch rules for exactly seven years, then dies. The rule then passes to the mate of that ruler, who rules for seven years and then dies. This pattern has repeated itself since the time of the Breaking of the World. The Sharans believe that the deaths are the "Will of the Pattern."

ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃænlɝz ɪn ʃɑɹə, noʊn əz ði aɪɑd, hu ɑɹ tætuɾ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ət bɝθ. ðə wɪmən ə ði aɪɑɾ ɛnfɔɹs ði aɪɑd lɔz stʃɹɪnʒəntli. ə sɛkʃuəl ɹileɪʃənʃɪp bɪtwin aɪɑɾ ən nɑn-aɪɑɾ ɪz pʌnɪʃəbəl baɪ dɛθ fəɹ ðə nɑn-aɪɑd, ən ði aɪɑɾ ɪz ɔlsoʊ ɛksəkjuɾəd ɪf fɔɹs ɑn ɪz əɹ əɹ pɑɹt kən bi pɹuvən. ɪf ə tʃaɪld ɪz bɔɹn ə ðə junjən, ɪts lɛft ɪkspoʊz tə ði ɛləməns, ən daɪz.

There are channelers in Shara, known as the Ayyad, who are tattooed on their faces at birth. The women of the Ayyad enforce the Ayyad laws stringently. A sexual relationship between Ayyad and non-Ayyad is punishable by death for the non-Ayyad, and the Ayyad is also executed if force on his or her part can be proven. If a child is born of the union, it is left exposed to the elements, and dies.

meɪl aɪɑɾ ɑɹ juzd əz bɹiɾɪŋ stɑk oʊnli. ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd ɪn ɛni fæʃən, nɑɾ ivən haʊ tə ɹiɾ əɹ ɹaɪt, ən wən ðeɪ ɹitʃ ðɛɹ twɛnti-fɝs jɪɹ əɹ bɪɡɪn tə tʃænəl, wɪtʃɛvɝ kʌmz fɝst, ðeɪ ɑɹ kɪld ən ðə bɑɾi kɹimeɪɾɪd. səpoʊzədli, ði aɪɑd tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ oʊnli ət ðə kəmæn ə ðə boʊn əɹ boʊt, hu ɪz ɔlweɪz sɝaʊndəd baɪ aɪɑd wɪmən.

Male Ayyad are used as breeding stock only. They are not educated in any fashion, not even how to read or write, and when they reach their twenty-first year or begin to channel, whichever comes first, they are killed and the body cremated. Supposedly, the Ayyad channel the One Power only at the command of the Sh'boan or Sh'botay, who is always surrounded by Ayyad women.

ivən ðə neɪm ə ðə læn ɪz ɪn daʊt. ðə neɪɾɪvz əv bɪn noʊn tə kɔl ɪt mɛni dɪfɹənt neɪmz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ʃəmɑɹə, koʊɾənsɪn, toʊmɑkə, kiɡɑli ən ʃɪbujə.

Even the name of the land is in doubt. The natives have been known to call it many different names, including Shamara, Co'dansin, Tomaka, Kigali and Shibouya.

ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd." (wʌn) ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi ɡɹup ə hɪɹoʊz u hæd mɛni ɛksplɔɪts, faɪnəli daɪɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪfɛns ə meɪnɛðɝən wən ðət lænd wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹoʊl-lɑk wɔɹz. (tu) ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən pʊt təɡɛðɝ ɔlmoʊs baɪ æksəɾənt baɪ mæt kɔθən ən ɔɹɡənaɪzd əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹsɪz dʊɹɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz kənsɪɾɝd ðə haɪɾ ə ðə mɪlətɛɹi ɑɹts, ðə deɪz ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ðə sɛntʃɝiz ɪmiɾiətli pɹisiɾɪŋ.

Shen an Calhar: In the Old Tongue, "the Band of the Red Hand." (1) A legendary group of heroes who had many exploits, finally dying in the defense of Manetheren when that land was destroyed during the Trol-loc Wars. (2) A military formation put together almost by accident by Mat Cauthon and organized along the lines of military forces during what is considered the height of the military arts, the days of Artur Hawkwing and the centuries immediately preceding.

sɪsnɛɹə, dɑɹlɪn: eɪ haɪ lɔɹɾ ɪn tɛɹ, hi wɑz fɔɹmɝli ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Sisnera, Darlin: A High Lord in Tear, he was formerly in rebellion against the Dragon Reborn.

æftɝ sɝvɪŋ fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt pɪɹiəɾ əz stuɝɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn tɛɹ, hi wɑz tʃoʊzən tə bi ðə fɝs kɪŋ ə tiɹ.

After serving for a short period as Steward of the Dragon Reborn in Tear, he was chosen to be the first king of Tear.

sneɪks ən fɑksəz: ə ɡeɪm ðəɾ ɪz mʌtʃ lʌv baɪ tʃɪlʒɹən əntɪl ðeɪ mətʃʊɹ ɪnʌf tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt kən nɛvɝ bi wʌn wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹulz. ɪts pleɪd wɪð ə bɔɹd ðəɾ əz ə wɛb ə laɪnz wɪð æɹoʊz ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ dɝɛkʃən. ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn dɪsks ɪŋkt wɪð tʃɹaɪæŋɡəlz tə ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə fɑksəz, ən tɛn dɪsks ɪŋkt wɪð weɪvi laɪnz tə ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə sneɪks. ðə ɡeɪm ɪz bɪɡʌn baɪ seɪɪŋ "kɝədʒ tə stʃɹɛŋθən, faɪɝ tə blaɪnd, mjuzɪk tə dæzəl, aɪɝn tə baɪnd," waɪl dɪskɹaɪbɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl wɪð ə weɪvi laɪn θɹu ɪt wɪð wʌnz hænd. daɪs ɑɹ ɹoʊl tə dətɝmən muvz fəɹ ðə pleɪɝz ən ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz. ɪf ə sneɪk əɹ fɑks lænz ɑn ə pleɪɝz pis, hiz aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪm, ən əz lɔŋ əz ðə ɹulz ɑɹ fɑloʊd, ðɪs ɔlweɪz hæpənz. si ɔlsoʊ æɛlfɪn, ɛlfɪn.

Snakes and Foxes: A game that is much loved by children until they mature enough to realize that it can never be won without breaking the rules. It is played with a board that has a web of lines with arrows indicating direction. There are ten discs inked with triangles to represent the foxes, and ten discs inked with wavy lines to represent the snakes. The game is begun by saying "Courage to strengthen, fire to blind, music to dazzle, iron to bind," while describing a triangle with a wavy line through it with one's hand. Dice are rolled to determine moves for the players and the snakes and foxes. If a snake or fox lands on a player's piece, he is out of the game, and as long as the rules are followed, this always happens. See also Aelfinn, Eelfinn.

sɔɪhɪn: ðə kloʊsəs tʃɹænzleɪʃən fɹəm ði oʊl tʌŋ wəd bi "ə haɪɾ əmʌŋ loʊnəs," ðoʊ səm tʃɹænzleɪɾ ɪɾ əz minɪŋ "boʊθ skaɪ ən væli" əmʌŋ sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz. sɔɪhɪn ɪz ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə hɝɛɾətɛɹi ʌpɝ sɝvəns. ðeɪ ɑɹ dækoʊvæl, pɹɑpɝɾi, jɛɾ ɑkjəpaɪ pəzɪʃənz ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl əθɔɹəɾi ən ɔfən paʊɝ. ivən ðə blʌd stɛp kɛɹfəli ɝaʊn sɔɪhɪn ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, ən spik tə sɔɪhɪn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf əz tə ikwəlz. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

so'jhin: The closest translation from the Old Tongue would be "a height among lowness," though some translate it as meaning "both sky and valley" among several other possibilities. So'jhin is the term applied by the Seanchan to hereditary upper servants. They are da'covale, property, yet occupy positions of considerable authority and often power. Even the Blood step carefully around so'jhin of the Imperial family, and speak to so'jhin of the Empress herself as to equals. See also da'covale.

stʌmp: ə pʌblɪk miɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ði oʊɡiɝ. ɪts pɹɪzaɪɾɪd oʊvɝ baɪ ðə kaʊnsəl ʌv ɛldɝz ʌv ə stɛɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ɛni ədʌlt oʊɡiɝ meɪ spik, əɹ meɪ tʃuz ən ædvəkət tə spik fəɹ hɪm. eɪ stʌmp ɪz ɔfən hɛld ət ðə lɑɹdʒəs tʃɹi stʌmp ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ, ən meɪ læs fəɹ sɛvɹəl jɪɹz. wən ə kwɛstʃən ɝaɪzəz ðəɾ əfɛks ɔl oʊɡiɝ, ə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp ɪz hɛld, ən oʊɡiɝ fɹəm ɔl stɛɾɪŋ mit tə ædʒɹɛs ðə kwɛstʃən. ðə vɛɹiəs stɛɾɪŋ teɪk tɝnz hoʊstɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp.

Stump: A public meeting among the Ogier. It is presided over by the Council of Elders of a stedding, but any adult Ogier may speak, or may choose an advocate to speak for him. A Stump is often held at the largest tree stump in a stedding, and may last for several years. When a question arises that affects all Ogier, a Great Stump is held, and Ogier from all stedding meet to address the question. The various stedding take turns hosting the Great Stump.
